"The Mayor and the Wisdom seldom agree," Tam said, "and they agreed less than usual today. That's all. It's the same in every village."

"wʌɾ əbaʊt ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən?" mæt æskt, ən pɛɹɪn æɾəd iɡɝ mɝmɝz. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

"What about the false Dragon?" Mat asked, and Perrin added eager murmurs. "What about the Aes Sedai?"

tæm ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sloʊli. "mæstɝ feɪn nu lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi toʊld. ət list, lɪɾəl ʌv ɪntʃɹəs tə ʌs. bæɾəlz wʌn əɹ lɔst. sɪɾiz teɪkən ən ɹəteɪkən. ɔl ɪn ɡildən, θæŋk ðə laɪt. ɪt hæzən spɹɛd, əɹ hæd nɑt ðə læs mæstɝ feɪn nu."

Tam shook his head slowly. "Master Fain knew little more than he had already told. At least, little of interest to us. Battles won or lost. Cities taken and retaken. All in Ghealdan, thank the Light. It hasn't spread, or had not the last Master Fain knew."

"bæɾəlz ɪntʃɹəs mi," mæt sɛd, ən pɛɹɪn æɾəd, "wʌt dɪɾ i seɪ əbaʊt ðɛm?"

"Battles interest me," Mat said, and Perrin added, "What did he say about them?"

"bæɾəlz doʊn ɪntʃɹəs mi, meɪtʃɹim," tæm sɛd. "bʌɾ aɪm ʃʊɹ hɪl bi ɡlæd tə tɛl jə ɔl əbaʊɾ əm leɪɾɝ. wʌt dʌz ɪntʃɹəs mi ɪz ðət wi ʃʊdn əv tə wɝi əbaʊɾ əm hɪɹ, əz fɑɹ əz ðə kaʊnsəl kən tɛl. wi kən si noʊ ɹizən fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə kʌm hɪɹ ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ saʊθ. ən əz fəɹ ðə ɹɪtɝn dʒɝni, ðeɪ ɑɹən laɪkli tə wɑnə kɹɔs ðə fɔɹəst ə ʃædoʊz ən swɪm ðə waɪt ɹɪvɝ."

"Battles don't interest me, Matrim," Tam said. "But I'm sure he will be glad to tell you all about them later. What does interest me is that we shouldn't have to worry about them here, as far as the Council can tell. We can see no reason for Aes Sedai to come here on their way south. And as for the return journey, they aren't likely to want to cross the Forest of Shadows and swim the White River."

ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz tʃʌkəld ət ði aɪdiə. ðəɹ wɝ θɹi ɹizənz waɪ noʊ wʌn keɪm ɪndə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɪksɛp fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ, baɪ weɪ ʌv tɛɹən fɛɹi. ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst, ɪn ðə wɛst, wɝ ðə fɝst, ʌv kɔɹs, ən ðə maɪɹ blɑk ði is dʒʌst əz ɪfɛktɪvli. tə ðə saʊθ wɑz ðə waɪt ɹɪvɝ, wɪtʃ ɡɑɾ ɪts neɪm fɹəm ðə weɪ ɹɑks ən boʊldɝz tʃɝn ɪts swɪft wɔɾɝz tə fɹɔθ. ən bɪɑn ðə waɪt leɪ ðə fɔɹəst ə ʃædoʊz. fju tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk hæɾ ɛvɝ kɹɔs ðə waɪt, ən fjuɝ stɪl ɹɪtɝn ɪf ðeɪ dɪd. ɪt wɑz dʒɛnɝəli əɡɹid, ðoʊ, ðət ðə fɔɹəst ə ʃædoʊz stʃɹɛtʃt saʊθ fəɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz əɹ mɔɹ wɪθaʊɾ ə ɹoʊɾ əɹ ə vɪlədʒ, bʌt wɪð plɛnti ʌv wʊlvz ən bɛɹz.

Rand and the others chuckled at the idea. There were three reasons why no one came into the Two Rivers except from the north, by way of Taren Ferry. The Mountains of Mist, in the west, were the first, of course, and the Mire blocked the east just as effectively. To the south was the White River, which got its name from the way rocks and boulders churned its swift waters to froth. And beyond the White lay the Forest of Shadows. Few Two Rivers folk had ever crossed the White, and fewer still returned if they did. It was generally agreed, though, that the Forest of Shadows stretched south for a hundred miles or more without a road or a village, but with plenty of wolves and bears.

"soʊ ðæts ən ɛn tə ɪt fəɹ ʌs," mæt sɛd. hi saʊndəɾ ət list ə lɪɾəl dɪsəpɔɪntɪd.

"So that's an end to it for us," Mat said. He sounded at least a little disappointed.

"nɑt kwaɪt," tæm sɛd. "deɪ æftɝ təmɑɹoʊ wɪl sɛn mɛn tə dɛvən ɹaɪɾ ən wɑtʃ hɪl, ən tɛɹən fɛɹi, tu, tə ɝeɪnʒ fəɹ ə wɑtʃ tə bi kɛpt. ɹaɪɾɝz əlɔŋ ðə waɪɾ ən ðə tɛɹən, boʊθ, ən pətʃɹoʊlz bɪtwin. ɪt ʃəd bi dʌn tədeɪ, bʌɾ oʊnli ðə meɪɝ əɡɹiz wɪð mi. ðə ɹɛs kæn si æskɪŋ ɛniwʌn tə spɛn bɛl taɪn ɔf ɹaɪɾɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə tu ɹɪvɝz."

"Not quite," Tam said. "Day after tomorrow we will send men to Deven Ride and Watch Hill, and Taren Ferry, too, to arrange for a watch to be kept. Riders along the White and the Taren, both, and patrols between. It should be done today, but only the Mayor agrees with me. The rest can't see asking anyone to spend Bel Tine off riding across the Two Rivers."

"bʌɾ aɪ θɔt jə sɛd wi dɪdn əv tə wɝi," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ən tæm ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

"But I thought you said we didn't have to worry," Perrin said, and Tam shook his head.

"aɪ sɛd ʃəd nɑt, bɔɪ, nɑt dɪd nɑt. aɪv sin mɛn daɪ kəz ðeɪ wɝ ʃʊɹ ðət wʌt ʃəd nɑt hæpən, wəd nɑt. bɪsaɪdz, ðə faɪɾɪŋ wɪl stɝ ʌp ɔl sɔɹts ə pipəl. moʊst wɪl dʒʌs bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn seɪfti, bʌɾ ʌðɝz wɪl bi lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ə weɪ tə pɹɑfət fɹəm ðə kənfjuʒən. wɪl ɔfɝ ɛni ʌv ðə fɝst ə hɛlpɪŋ hænd, bʌt wi mʌs bi ɹɛɾi tə sɛn ðə sɛkən taɪp ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ."

"I said should not, boy, not did not. I've seen men die because they were sure that what should not happen, would not. Besides, the fighting will stir up all sorts of people. Most will just be trying to find safety, but others will be looking for a way to profit from the confusion. We'll offer any of the first a helping hand, but we must be ready to send the second type on their way."

əbɹʌpli mæt spoʊk ʌp. "kæn wi bi pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt? aɪ wɑn tə, ɛniweɪ. jə noʊ aɪ kən ɹaɪɾ əz wɛl əz ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ."

Abruptly Mat spoke up. "Can we be part of it? I want to, anyway. You know I can ride as well as anyone in the village."

"ju wɑn ə fju wiks ə koʊld, bɔɹɾəm, ən slipɪŋ ɹʌf?" tæm tʃʌkəld. "laɪkli ðæts ɔl ðəɹ wɪl bi tə ɪt. aɪ hoʊp ðæts ɔl. wɝ wɛl aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ ivən fəɹ ɹɛfjudʒiz. bʌt jə kən spik tə mæstɝ ælvɪɹ ɪf jəɹ maɪn ɪz meɪɾ ʌp. ɹænd, ɪts taɪm fəɹ əs tə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ bæk tə ðə fɑɹm."

"You want a few weeks of cold, boredom, and sleeping rough?" Tam chuckled. "Likely that's all there will be to it. I hope that's all. We're well out of the way even for refugees. But you can speak to Master al'Vere if your mind is made up. Rand, it's time for us to be getting back to the farm."

ɹænd blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "aɪ θɔt wi wɝ steɪɪŋ fəɹ wɪntɝnaɪt."

Rand blinked in surprise. "I thought we were staying for Winternight."

"θɪŋz nid siɪŋ tə ət ðə fɑɹm, ən aɪ nid jə wɪð mi."

"Things need seeing to at the farm, and I need you with me."

"ivən soʊ, wi doʊn əv tə liv fəɹ aʊɝz jɛt. ən aɪ wɑnə vɑləntɪɹ fəɹ ðə pətʃɹoʊlz, tu."

"Even so, we don't have to leave for hours yet. And I want to volunteer for the patrols, too."

"wi ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ naʊ," hɪz fɑðɝ ɹɪplaɪɾ ɪn ə toʊn ðət bɹʊk noʊ ɑɹɡjəmənt. ɪn ə sɑftɝ vɔɪs i æɾəd, "wil bi bæk təmɑɹoʊ ɪn plɛnti ʌv taɪm fəɹ jə tə spik tə ðə meɪɝ. ən plɛnti ʌv taɪm fəɹ fɛstəvəl, tu. faɪv mɪnəts, naʊ, ðən mit mi ɪn ðə steɪbəl."

"We are going now," his father replied in a tone that brooked no argument. In a softer voice he added, "We'll be back tomorrow in plenty of time for you to speak to the Mayor. And plenty of time for Festival, too. Five minutes, now, then meet me in the stable."

"ɑɹ jə gɑnə dʒɔɪn ɹænd ən mi ɑn ðə wɑtʃ?" mæt æsk pɛɹɪn əz tæm lɛft. "aɪl bɛt ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs ɛvɝ hæpən ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz bɪfɔɹ. waɪ, ɪf wi ɡɛɾ ʌp tə ðə tɛɹən, wi maɪɾ ivən si soʊlʒɝz, əɹ u noʊz wʌt. ivən tɪŋkɝz."

"Are you going to join Rand and me on the watch?" Mat asked Perrin as Tam left. "I'll bet there's nothing like this ever happened in the Two Rivers before. Why, if we get up to the Taren, we might even see soldiers, or who knows what. Even Tinkers."

"aɪ ɪkspɛkt aɪ wɪl," pɛɹɪn sɛd sloʊli, "ɪf mæstɝ luhən dʌznt nid mi, ðəɾ ɪz."

"I expect I will," Perrin said slowly, "if Master Luhhan doesn't need me, that is."

"ðə wɔɹ ɪz ɪn ɡildən," ɹænd snæpt. wɪð ən ɛfɝɾ i loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs. "ðə wɔɹ ɪz ɪn ɡildən, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ ðə laɪt noʊz wɛɹ, bʌt nʌn ʌv ɪts hɪɹ. ðə mæn ɪn ðə blæk kloʊk ɪz, əɹ əv jə fɝɡɑɾən ɪm ɔlɹɛɾi?" ði ʌðɝz ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɪmbɛɹəs lʊks.

"The war is in Ghealdan," Rand snapped. With an effort he lowered his voice. "The war is in Ghealdan, and the Aes Sedai are the Light knows where, but none of it is here. The man in the black cloak is, or have you forgotten him already?" The others exchanged embarrassed looks.

"sɑɹi, ɹænd," mæt mʌɾɝd. "bʌɾ ə tʃæns tə də sʌmθɪŋ bɪsaɪdz mɪlk maɪ dɑz kaʊz dʌzn kʌm əlɔŋ vɛɹi ɔfən." hi stʃɹeɪɾənd ʌndɝ ðɛɹ stɑɹɾəld stɛɹz. "wɛl, aɪ də mɪlk ðɛm, ən ɛvɹi deɪ, tu."

"Sorry, Rand," Mat muttered. "But a chance to do something besides milk my da's cows doesn't come along very often." He straightened under their startled stares. "Well, I do milk them, and every day, too."

"ðə blæk ɹaɪɾɝ," ɹænd ɹimaɪndəd ðɛm. "wʌɾ ɪf i hɝts sʌmbɑɾi?"

"The black rider," Rand reminded them. "What if he hurts somebody?"

"meɪbi hiz ə ɹɛfjʊdʒi fɹəm ðə wɔɹ," pɛɹɪn sɛd daʊtfəli.

"Maybe he's a refugee from the war," Perrin said doubtfully.

"wʌtɛvɝ i ɪz," mæt sɛd, "ðə wɑtʃ wɪl faɪn hɪm."

"Whatever he is," Mat said, "the watch will find him."

"meɪbi," ɹænd sɛd, "bʌɾ i simz tə dɪsəpɪɹ wən i wɑns tə. ɪt maɪt bi bɛɾɝ ɪf ðeɪ nu tə lʊk fəɹ hɪm."

"Maybe," Rand said, "but he seems to disappear when he wants to. It might be better if they knew to look for him."

"wil tɛl mæstɝ ælvɪɹ wən wi vɑləntɪɹ fəɹ ðə pətʃɹoʊlz," mæt sɛd, "hil tɛl ðə kaʊnsəl, ən ðəl tɛl ðə wɑtʃ."

"We'll tell Master al'Vere when we volunteer for the patrols," Mat said, "he'll tell the Council, and they'll tell the watch."

"ðə kaʊnsəl!" pɛɹɪn sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "wid bi lʌki ɪf ðə meɪɝ dɪdn læf aʊt laʊd. mæstɝ luhən ən ɹændz fɑðɝ ɔlɹɛɾi θɪŋk ðə tu ʌv əs ɑɹ dʒʌmpɪŋ ət ʃædoʊz."

"The Council!" Perrin said incredulously. "We'd be lucky if the Mayor didn't laugh out loud. Master Luhhan and Rand's father already think the two of us are jumping at shadows."

ɹænd saɪd. "ɪf wɝ gɑnə də ɪt, wi maɪɾ əz wɛl də ɪt naʊ. hi woʊn læf ɛni laʊɾɝ tədeɪ ðən hɪl təmɑɹoʊ."

Rand sighed. "If we're going to do it, we might as well do it now. He won't laugh any louder today than he will tomorrow."

"meɪbi," pɛɹɪn sɛd wɪð ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlæns ət mæt, "wi ʃəd tʃɹaɪ faɪndɪŋ səm ʌðɝz huv sin hɪm. wɪl si dʒʌst əbaʊɾ ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ tənaɪt." mæts skaʊl dipənd, bʌɾ i stɪl dɪd nɑt seɪ ɛniθɪŋ. ɔl ə ðɛm ʌndɝstʊd ðət pɛɹɪn mɛn ðeɪ ʃəd faɪnd wɪtnəsəz u wɝ mɔɹ ɹɪlaɪəbəl ðən mæt. "hi woʊn læf ɛni laʊɾɝ təmɑɹoʊ," pɛɹɪn æɾəd wən ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "æn aɪd dʒʌst əz sun əv sʌmbɑɾi ɛls wɪð əs wən wi ɡoʊ tə hɪm. hæf ðə vɪlədʒ wəd sut mi faɪn."

"Maybe," Perrin said with a sidelong glance at Mat, "we should try finding some others who've seen him. We'll see just about everybody in the village tonight." Mat's scowl deepened, but he still did not say anything. All of them understood that Perrin meant they should find witnesses who were more reliable than Mat. "He won't laugh any louder tomorrow," Perrin added when Rand hesitated. "And I'd just as soon have somebody else with us when we go to him. Half the village would suit me fine."

ɹænd nɑɾəd sloʊli. hi kəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hɪɹ mæstɝ ælvɪɹ læfɪŋ. mɔɹ wɪtnəsəz sɝɾənli kəd nɑt hɝt. ən ɪf θɹi ʌv əm hæd sin ðə fɛloʊ, ʌðɝz hæd tə hæv, tu. ðeɪ mʌs hæv. "təmɑɹoʊ, ðɛn. jə tu faɪn huɛvɝ jə kən tənaɪt, ən təmɑɹoʊ wi ɡoʊ tə ðə meɪɝ. æftɝ ðæt. . . ." ðeɪ lʊkt əɾ ɪm saɪlənli, noʊ wʌn ɹeɪzɪŋ ðə kwɛstʃən ʌv wʌt hæpən ɪf ðeɪ kəd nɑt faɪn ɛniwʌn ɛls u hæd sin ðə blæk-kloʊk mæn. ðə kwɛstʃən wɑz klɪɹ ɪn ðɛɹ aɪz, ðoʊ, ən i hæd noʊ ænsɝ. hi saɪd hɛvəli. "aɪd bɛɾɝ ɡoʊ, naʊ. maɪ fɑðɝ wɪl bi wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf aɪ fɛl ɪndə ə hoʊl."

Rand nodded slowly. He could already hear Master al'Vere laughing. More witnesses certainly could not hurt. And if three of them had seen the fellow, others had to have, too. They must have. "Tomorrow, then. You two find whoever you can tonight, and tomorrow we go to the Mayor. After that. . . ." They looked at him silently, no one raising the question of what happened if they could not find anyone else who had seen the black-cloaked man. The question was clear in their eyes, though, and he had no answer. He sighed heavily. "I'd better go, now. My father will be wondering if I fell into a hole."

fɑloʊd baɪ ðɛɹ ɡʊdbaɪz, hi tʃɹɑɾəd ɝaʊn tə ðə steɪbliɑɹd wɛɹ ðə haɪ-wil kɑɹt stʊd pɹɑpt ɑn ɪts ʃæfs.

Followed by their goodbyes, he trotted around to the stableyard where the high-wheeled cart stood propped on its shafts.

ðə steɪbəl wɑz ə lɔŋ, nɛɹoʊ bɪldɪŋ, tɑp baɪ ə haɪ-pikt, θætʃt ɹuf. stɔlz, ðɛɹ flɔɹz kʌvɝd wɪð stʃɹɔ, fɪl boʊθ saɪdz ə ðə dɪm ɪntɪɹiɝ, lɪɾ oʊnli baɪ ði oʊpən dʌbəl dɔɹz əɾ iðɝ ɛnd. ðə pɛdlɝz tim mʌntʃt ðɛɹ oʊts ɪn eɪt stɔlz, ən mæstɝ ælvɪɹz mæsɪv dɝənz, ðə tim i haɪɝɾ aʊt wən fɑɹmɝz hæd hɔlɪŋ bɪɑn ði əbɪləɾiz ə ðɛɹ oʊn hɔɹsəz, fɪl sɪks mɔɹ, bʌɾ oʊnli θɹi ʌðɝz wɝ ɑkjəpaɪd. ɹænd θɔɾ i kəd mætʃ ʌp hɔɹs ən ɹaɪɾɝ wɪð noʊ tʃɹʌbəl. ðə tɔl, dip-tʃɛstəd blæk stæljən ðət swʌŋ ʌp ɪz hɛd fɪɹsli hæd tə bi lænz. ðə slik waɪt mɛɹ wɪð ən ɑɹtʃt nɛk, hɝ kwɪk stɛps əz ɡɹeɪsfəl əz ə ɡɝl dænsɪŋ, ivən ɪn ðə stɔl, kəɾ oʊnli bɪlɔŋ tə mɔɪɹeɪn. ən ðə θɝɾ ʌnfəmɪljɝ hɔɹs, ə ɹeɪnʒi, slæb-saɪɾəd ɡɛldɪŋ ʌv ə dʌsti bɹaʊn, fɪt tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn pɝfəkli.

The stable was a long, narrow building, topped by a high-peaked, thatched roof. Stalls, their floors covered with straw, filled both sides of the dim interior, lit only by the open double doors at either end. The peddler's team munched their oats in eight stalls, and Master al'Vere's massive Dhurrans, the team he hired out when farmers had hauling beyond the abilities of their own horses, filled six more, but only three others were occupied. Rand thought he could match up horse and rider with no trouble. The tall, deep-chested black stallion that swung up his head fiercely had to be Lan's. The sleek white mare with an arched neck, her quick steps as graceful as a girl dancing, even in the stall, could only belong to Moiraine. And the third unfamiliar horse, a rangy, slab-sided gelding of a dusty brown, fit Thom Merrilin perfectly.

tæm stʊɾ ɪn ðə ɹɪɹ ə ðə steɪbəl, hoʊldɪŋ bɛlə baɪ ə lɛd ɹoʊp ən spikɪŋ kwaɪətli tə hu ən tæd. bɪfɔɹ ɹænd hæd teɪkən tu stɛps ɪndə ðə steɪbəl ɪz fɑðɝ nɑɾəd tə ðə steɪbəlmən ən bɹɔt bɛlə aʊt, wɝdləsli ɡæðɝɪŋ ʌp ɹænd əz i wɛnt.

Tam stood in the rear of the stable, holding Bela by a lead rope and speaking quietly to Hu and Tad. Before Rand had taken two steps into the stable his father nodded to the stablemen and brought Bela out, wordlessly gathering up Rand as he went.

ðeɪ hɑɹnəs ðə ʃæɡi mɛɹ ɪn saɪləns. tæm əpɪɹd soʊ dip ɪn θɔt ðət ɹænd hɛld ɪz tʌŋ. hi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənvɪns ɪz fɑðɝ əbaʊt ðə blæk-kloʊkt ɹaɪɾɝ, mʌtʃ lɛs ðə meɪɝ. təmɑɹoʊ wəɾ əv tə bi taɪm ɪnʌf, wən mæt ən ðə ɹɛs hæd faʊn ʌðɝz u hæd sin ðə mæn. ɪf ðeɪ faʊn ʌðɝz.

They harnessed the shaggy mare in silence. Tam appeared so deep in thought that Rand held his tongue. He did not really look forward to trying to convince his father about the black-cloaked rider, much less the Mayor. Tomorrow would have to be time enough, when Mat and the rest had found others who had seen the man. If they found others.

əz ðə kɑɹt lɝtʃt ɪndə moʊʃən, ɹænd tʊk ɪz baʊ ən kwɪvɝ fɹəm ðə bæk, ɔkwɝdli bɛltɪŋ ðə kwɪvɝ əɾ ɪz weɪst əz i hæf tʃɹɑɾəd əlɔŋsaɪd. wən ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə læst ɹoʊ ʌv haʊsəz ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ, hi nɑkt ən æɹoʊ, kæɹiɪŋ ɪt hæf ɹeɪzd ən pɑɹtli dʒɹɔn. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə si ɪksɛp moʊsli lifləs tʃɹiz, bʌɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz taɪɾənd. ðə blæk ɹaɪɾɝ kəd bi ɑn əm bɪfɔɹ iðɝ ə ðɛm nu ɪt. ðəɹ maɪt nɑt bi taɪm tə dʒɹɔ ðə baʊ ɪf i wɑz nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hæfweɪ tə ɪt.

As the cart lurched into motion, Rand took his bow and quiver from the back, awkwardly belting the quiver at his waist as he half trotted alongside. When they reached the last row of houses in the village, he nocked an arrow, carrying it half raised and partly drawn. There was nothing to see except mostly leafless trees, but his shoulders tightened. The black rider could be on them before either of them knew it. There might not be time to draw the bow if he was not already halfway to it.

hi nu hi kəd nɑt kip ʌp ðə tɛnʃən ɑn ðə bɑstʃɹɪŋ fəɹ lɔŋ. hi hæd meɪd ðə baʊ hɪmsɛlf, ən tæm wɑz wʌn ə ðə fju ʌðɝz ɪn ðə dɪstʃɹɪkt u kəɾ ivən dʒɹɔ ɪɾ ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə tʃik. hi kæst ɝaʊn fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə teɪk ɪz maɪn ɔf θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə dɑɹk ɹaɪɾɝ. sɝaʊndəd baɪ ðə fɔɹəst, ðɛɹ kloʊks flæpɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd, ɪt wɑz nɑɾ izi.

He knew he could not keep up the tension on the bowstring for long. He had made the bow himself, and Tam was one of the few others in the district who could even draw it all the way to the cheek. He cast around for something to take his mind off thinking about the dark rider. Surrounded by the forest, their cloaks flapping in the wind, it was not easy.

"fɑðɝ," hi sɛd faɪnəli, "aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd waɪ ðə kaʊnsəl hæd tə kwɛstʃən pdən feɪn." wɪð ən ɛfɝɾ i tʊk ɪz aɪz ɔf ðə wʊdz ən lʊkt əkɹɔs bɛlə ət tæm. "ɪt simz tə mi, ðə dɪsɪʒən jə ɹitʃt cʊɾə bɪn meɪd ɹaɪɾ ɑn ðə spɑt. ðə meɪɝ fɹaɪɾənd ɛvɹibɑɾi hæf aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ wɪts, tɔkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən hɪɹ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz."

"Father," he said finally, "I don't understand why the Council had to question Padan Fain." With an effort he took his eyes off the woods and looked across Bela at Tam. "It seems to me, the decision you reached could have been made right on the spot. The Mayor frightened everybody half out of their wits, talking about Aes Sedai and the false Dragon here in the Two Rivers."

"pipəl ɑɹ fʌni, ɹænd. ðə bɛst ə ðɛm ɑɹ. teɪk hɹəl luhən. mæstɝ luhən ɪz ə stʃɹɔŋ mæn, ən ə bɹeɪv wʌn, bʌɾ i kæn bɛɹ tə si bʊtʃɝɪŋ dʌn. tɝnz peɪl əz ə ʃit."

"People are funny, Rand. The best of them are. Take Haral Luhhan. Master Luhhan is a strong man, and a brave one, but he can't bear to see butchering done. Turns pale as a sheet."

"wʌt dʌz ðəɾ əv tə də wɪð ɛniθɪŋ? ɛvɹibɑɾi noʊz mæstɝ luhən kæn stæn ðə saɪɾ ə blʌd, ən noʊbɑdi bʌt ðə kɑplɪnz ən ðə kɔŋɡɝz θɪŋks ɛniθɪŋ ʌv ɪt."

"What does that have to do with anything? Everybody knows Master Luhhan can't stand the sight of blood, and nobody but the Coplins and the Congars thinks anything of it."

"dʒʌs ðɪs, læd. pipəl doʊn ɔlweɪz θɪŋk əɹ bɪheɪv ðə weɪ jə maɪt bɪliv ðeɪ wʊd. ðoʊz foʊk bæk ðəɹ . . . lɛt ðə heɪl bit ðɛɹ kɹɑps ɪndə ðə mʌd, ən ðə wɪn teɪk ɔf ɛvɹi ɹuf ɪn ðə dɪstʃɹɪkt, ən ðə wʊlvz kɪl hæf ðɛɹ laɪvstɑk, ən ðəl ɹoʊl ʌp ðɛɹ slivz ən stɑɹt fɹəm skɹætʃ. ðəl ɡɹʌmbəl, bʌt ðeɪ woʊnt weɪst ɛni taɪm wɪð ɪt. bʌt jə ɡɪv əm dʒʌs ðə θɔɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən ɪn ɡildən, ən sun ɪnʌf ðəl stɑɹt θɪŋkɪŋ ðət ɡildən ɪz nɑt ðət fɑɹ ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə fɔɹəst ə ʃædoʊz, ən ə stʃɹeɪt laɪn fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn tə ɡildən wʊdn pæs ðət mʌtʃ tə ði ist ʌv ʌs. əz ɪf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wʊdn teɪk ðə ɹoʊd θɹu keɪɛmlɪn ən luɡɹɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə tʃɹævlɪŋ kɹɔs-kʌntʃɹi! baɪ təmɑɹoʊ mɔɹnɪŋ hæf ðə vɪlədʒ wʊɾə bɪn ʃʊɹ ði ɪntaɪɝ wɔɹ wɑz əbaʊt tə dɪsɛn ɑn ʌs. ɪt wəd teɪk wiks tə əndu. ə faɪn bɛl taɪn ðət wəd meɪk. soʊ bɹæn ɡeɪv əm ði aɪdiə bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəd ɡɛɾ ɪt fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz.

"Just this, lad. People don't always think or behave the way you might believe they would. Those folk back there . . . let the hail beat their crops into the mud, and the wind take off every roof in the district, and the wolves kill half their livestock, and they'll roll up their sleeves and start from scratch. They'll grumble, but they won't waste any time with it. But you give them just the thought of Aes Sedai and a false Dragon in Ghealdan, and soon enough they'll start thinking that Ghealdan is not that far the other side of the Forest of Shadows, and a straight line from Tar Valon to Ghealdan wouldn't pass that much to the east of us. As if the Aes Sedai wouldn't take the road through Caemlyn and Lugard instead of traveling cross-country! By tomorrow morning half the village would have been sure the entire war was about to descend on us. It would take weeks to undo. A fine Bel Tine that would make. So Bran gave them the idea before they could get it for themselves.

"ðeɪv sin ðə kaʊnsəl teɪk ðə pɹɑbləm ʌndɝ kənsɪɾɝeɪʃən, ən baɪ naʊ ðəl bi hɪɹɪŋ wʌt wi dɪsaɪɾɪd. ðeɪ tʃoʊz əs fəɹ ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl kəz ðeɪ tʃɹʌst wi kən ɹizən θɪŋz aʊɾ ɪn ðə bɛst weɪ fəɹ ɛvɹibɑɾi. ðeɪ tʃɹʌst əɹ əpɪnjənz. ivən sɛnz, wɪtʃ dʌzn seɪ mʌtʃ fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs, aɪ səpoʊz. əɾ ɛni ɹeɪt, ðəl hɪɹ ðəɹ ɪzən ɛniθɪŋ tə wɝi əbaʊt, ən ðəl bɪliv ɪt. ɪts nɑt ðət ðeɪ kʊdn ɹitʃ ðə seɪm kənkluʒən, əɹ wəd nɑt, ɪvɛntʃəwəli, bʌt ðɪs weɪ wi woʊn əv fɛstəvəl ɹuənd, ən noʊbɑdi hæz tə spɛnd wiks wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ ðəɾ ɪzən laɪkli tə hæpən. ɪf ɪt dʌz, əɡɛnst ɔl ɑdz . . . wɛl, ðə pətʃɹoʊlz wɪl ɡɪv əs ɪnʌf wɔɹnɪŋ tə də wʌt wi kæn. aɪ tʃɹuli doʊn θɪŋk ɪɾəl kʌm tə ðæt, ðoʊ."

"They've seen the Council take the problem under consideration, and by now they'll be hearing what we decided. They chose us for the Village Council because they trust we can reason things out in the best way for everybody. They trust our opinions. Even Cenn's, which doesn't say much for the rest of us, I suppose. At any rate, they will hear there isn't anything to worry about, and they'll believe it. It is not that they couldn't reach the same conclusion, or would not, eventually, but this way we won't have Festival ruined, and nobody has to spend weeks worrying about something that isn't likely to happen. If it does, against all odds . . . well, the patrols will give us enough warning to do what we can. I truly don't think it will come to that, though."

ɹænd pʌft aʊɾ ɪz tʃiks. əpɛɹənli, biɪŋ ɑn ðə kaʊnsəl wɑz mɔɹ kɑmpləkeɪɾəd ðən i hæd bɪlivd. ðə kɑɹt ɹʌmbəld ɑn əlɔŋ ðə kwɔɹi ɹoʊd.

Rand puffed out his cheeks. Apparently, being on the Council was more complicated than he had believed. The cart rumbled on along the Quarry Road.

"dɪɾ ɛniwʌn bɪsaɪdz pɛɹɪn si ðɪs stʃɹeɪnʒ ɹaɪɾɝ?" tæm æskt.

"Did anyone besides Perrin see this strange rider?" Tam asked.

"mæt dɪd, bʌt - " ɹænd blɪŋkt, ðən stɛɹɾ əkɹɔs bɛləz bæk əɾ ɪz fɑðɝ. "ju bɪliv mi? aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ bæk. aɪ hæv tə tɛl ðɛm." tæmz ʃaʊt hɔltəɾ ɪm əz i tɝn tə ɹʌn bæk tə ðə vɪlədʒ.

"Mat did, but - " Rand blinked, then stared across Bela's back at his father. "You believe me? I have to go back. I have to tell them." Tam's shout halted him as he turned to run back to the village.

"hoʊld, læd, hoʊld! dʒju θɪŋk aɪ weɪɾəd ðɪs lɔŋ tə spik fəɹ noʊ ɹizən?"

"Hold, lad, hold! Do you think I waited this long to speak for no reason?"

ɹɪlʌktənli ɹænd kɛpt ɑn bɪsaɪd ðə kɑɹt, stɪl kɹikɪŋ əlɔŋ bɪhaɪn peɪʃən bɛlə. "wʌt meɪd jə tʃeɪnʒ jəɹ maɪnd? waɪ kæn aɪ tɛl ði ʌðɝz?"

Reluctantly Rand kept on beside the cart, still creaking along behind patient Bela. "What made you change your mind? Why can't I tell the others?"

"ðeɪl noʊ sun ɪnʌf. ət list, pɛɹɪn wɪl. mæt, ɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ ʌv. wɝd mʌs bi ɡɑɾən tə ðə fɑɹmz əz bɛst ɪt kæn, bʌɾ ɪn ənʌðɝ aʊɝ ðəɹ woʊn bi ɛniwʌn ɪn ɛmənz fild əbʌv sɪkstin, ðoʊz u kən bi ɹispɑnsəbəl əbaʊɾ ɪt, ət list, hu dʌznt noʊ ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ ɪz skʌlkɪŋ ɝaʊn ən laɪkli nɑt ðə sɔɹt jə wəɾ ɪnvaɪt tə fɛstəvəl. ðə wɪntɝ əz bɪn bæɾ ɪnʌf wɪθaʊt ðɪs tə skɛɹ ðə jʌŋ wʌnz."

"They'll know soon enough. At least, Perrin will. Mat, I'm not sure of. Word must be gotten to the farms as best it can, but in another hour there won't be anyone in Emond's Field above sixteen, those who can be responsible about it, at least, who doesn't know a stranger is skulking around and likely not the sort you would invite to Festival. The winter has been bad enough without this to scare the young ones."

"fɛstəvəl?" ɹænd sɛd. "ɪf jə hæd sin ɪm jə wʊdnt wɑn ɪm kloʊsɝ ðən tɛn maɪlz. ə hʌnʒɹəd, meɪbi."

"Festival?" Rand said. "If you had seen him you wouldn't want him closer than ten miles. A hundred, maybe."

"pɝhæps soʊ," tæm sɛd plɑtʃədli. "hi kəd bi dʒʌst ə ɹɛfjʊdʒi fɹəm ðə tʃɹʌbəlz ɪn ɡildən, əɹ mɔɹ laɪkli ə θif u θɪŋks ðə pɪkɪŋz wɪl bi iziɝ hɪɹ ðən ɪn bɛɹlən əɹ tɛɹən fɛɹi. ivən soʊ, noʊ wʌn ɝaʊn hɪɹ əz soʊ mʌtʃ ðeɪ kən əfɔɹd tə hæv ɪt stoʊlən. ɪf ðə mæn ɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪskeɪp ðə wɔɹ . . . wɛl, ðæts stɪl noʊ ɪkskjus fəɹ skɛɹɪŋ pipəl. wʌns ðə wɑtʃ ɪz maʊntəd, ɪt ʃəɾ iðɝ faɪn ɪm əɹ fɹaɪɾən ɪm ɔf."

"Perhaps so," Tam said placidly. "He could be just a refugee from the troubles in Ghealdan, or more likely a thief who thinks the pickings will be easier here than in Baerlon or Taren Ferry. Even so, no one around here has so much they can afford to have it stolen. If the man is trying to escape the war . . . well, that's still no excuse for scaring people. Once the watch is mounted, it should either find him or frighten him off."

"aɪ hoʊp ɪt fɹaɪɾənz ɪm ɔf. bʌt waɪ dʒju bɪliv mi naʊ, wən jə dɪdn ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ?"

"I hope it frightens him off. But why do you believe me now, when you didn't this morning?"

"aɪ hæd tə bɪliv maɪ oʊn aɪz ðɛn, læd, ən aɪ sɔ nʌθɪŋ." tæm ʃʊk ɪz ɡɹɪzəl hɛd. "oʊnli jʌŋ mɛn si ðɪs fɛloʊ, ɪt simz. wən hɹəl luhən mɛnʃən pɛɹɪn dʒʌmpɪŋ ʃædoʊz, ðoʊ, ɪɾ ɔl keɪm aʊt. dʒɑn θeɪnz oʊldəst sʌn sɔ hɪm, tu, ən soʊ dɪd səmɛl kɹeɪz bɔɪ, bænʒɹi. wɛl, wən fɔɹ ə jə seɪ juv sin ə θɪŋ - ən sɑləd lædz, ɔl - wi stɑɹt θɪŋkɪŋ meɪbi ɪts ðəɹ wɛðɝ wi kən si ɪɾ əɹ nɑt. ɔl ɪksɛp sɛn, ʌv kɔɹs. ɛniweɪ, ðæts waɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ hoʊm. wɪð boʊθ ʌv əs əweɪ, ðɪs stʃɹeɪnʒɝ kəd bi ʌp tə ɛni kaɪndə mɪstʃəf ðɛɹ. ɪf nɑt fəɹ fɛstəvəl, aɪ wʊdn kʌm bæk təmɑɹoʊ, iðɝ. bʌt wi kæn meɪk aʊɝsɛlvz pɹɪznɝz ɪn əɹ oʊn hoʊmz dʒʌs kəz ðɪs fɛloʊ ɪz lɝkɪŋ əbaʊt."

"I had to believe my own eyes then, lad, and I saw nothing." Tam shook his grizzled head. "Only young men see this fellow, it seems. When Haral Luhhan mentioned Perrin jumping shadows, though, it all came out. Jon Thane's oldest son saw him, too, and so did Samel Crawe's boy, Bandry. Well, when four of you say you've seen a thing - and solid lads, all - we start thinking maybe it's there whether we can see it or not. All except Cenn, of course. Anyway, that's why we're going home. With both of us away, this stranger could be up to any kind of mischief there. If not for Festival, I wouldn't come back tomorrow, either. But we can't make ourselves prisoners in our own homes just because this fellow is lurking about."

"aɪ dɪdnt noʊ əbaʊt bæn əɹ lɛm," ɹænd sɛd. "ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə meɪɝ təmɑɹoʊ, bʌt wi wɝ wɝiɾ i wʊdn bɪliv ʌs, iðɝ."

"I didn't know about Ban or Lem," Rand said. "The rest of us were going to the Mayor tomorrow, but we were worried he wouldn't believe us, either."

"ɡɹeɪ hɛɹz doʊn min əɹ bɹeɪnz əv kɝɾəld," tæm sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "soʊ jə kip ə ʃɑɹp aɪ. meɪbi əl kætʃ saɪɾ ə hɪm, tu, ɪf i ʃoʊz ʌp əɡɛn."

"Gray hairs don't mean our brains have curdled," Tam said dryly. "So you keep a sharp eye. Maybe I'll catch sight of him, too, if he shows up again."

ɹænd sɛɾəld daʊn tə də dʒʌs ðæt. hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪz stɛp fɛlt laɪɾɝ. ðə nɑts wɝ ɡɔn fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. hi wɑz stɪl skɛɹd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ bæɾ əz ɪt hæd bɪn. tæm ən i wɝ dʒʌst əz əloʊn ɑn ðə kwɔɹi ɹoʊɾ əz ðeɪ hæd bɪn ðət mɔɹnɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪn səm weɪ hi fɛlt əz ɪf ði ɪntaɪɝ vɪlədʒ wɝ wɪð ðɛm. ðəɾ ʌðɝz nu ən bɪliv meɪɾ ɔl ðə dɪfɝəns. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ðə blæk-kloʊk hɔɹsmən kəd də ðət ðə pipəl ʌv ɛmənz fil kəd nɑt hændəl təɡɛðɝ.

Rand settled down to do just that. He was surprised to realize that his step felt lighter. The knots were gone from his shoulders. He was still scared, but it was not so bad as it had been. Tam and he were just as alone on the Quarry Road as they had been that morning, but in some way he felt as if the entire village were with them. That others knew and believed made all the difference. There was nothing the black-cloaked horseman could do that the people of Emond's Field could not handle together.


tʃæptɝ faɪv


CHAPTER 5

wɪntɝnaɪt


Winternight

ðə sʌn stʊd hæfweɪ daʊn fɹəm ɪts nundeɪ haɪ baɪ ðə taɪm ðə kɑɹt ɹitʃt ðə fɑɹmhaʊs. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə bɪɡ haʊs, nɑt nɪɹli soʊ lɑɹdʒ əz səm ə ðə spɹɔlɪŋ fɑɹmhaʊsəz tə ði ist, dwɛlɪŋz ðət hæd ɡɹoʊn oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz tə hoʊld ɪntaɪɝ fæmliz. ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ðəɾ ɔfən ɪnkluɾəd θɹi əɹ fɔɹ dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz ʌndɝ wʌn ɹuf, ɪnkluɾɪŋ æns, ʌŋkəlz, kʌzənz, ən nɛfjuz. tæm ən ɹænd wɝ kənsɪɾɝd aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi əz mʌtʃ fəɹ biɪŋ tu mɛn lɪvɪŋ əloʊn əz fəɹ fɑɹmɪŋ ɪn ðə wɛstwʊd.

The sun stood halfway down from its noonday high by the time the cart reached the farmhouse. It was not a big house, not nearly so large as some of the sprawling farmhouses to the east, dwellings that had grown over the years to hold entire families. In the Two Rivers that often included three or four generations under one roof, including aunts, uncles, cousins, and nephews. Tam and Rand were considered out of the ordinary as much for being two men living alone as for farming in the Westwood.

hɪɹ moʊst ə ðə ɹumz wɝ ɑn wʌn flɔɹ, ə nit ɹɛktæŋɡəl wɪð noʊ wɪŋz əɹ ədɪʃənz. tu bɛdʒɹumz ən ən æɾɪk stɔɹɹum fɪɾəd ʌp ʌndɝ ðə stipli sləp θætʃ. ɪf ðə waɪtwɑʃ wɑz ɔl bʌt ɡɔn fɹəm ðə staʊt wʊɾən wɔlz æftɝ ðə wɪntɝ stɔɹmz, ðə haʊs wɑz stɪl ɪn ə taɪɾi steɪɾ ə ɹɪpɛɹ, ðə θætʃ taɪtli mɛndɪɾ ən ðə dɔɹz ən ʃʌɾɝz wɛl-hʌŋ ən snʌɡ-fɪɾɪŋ.

Here most of the rooms were on one floor, a neat rectangle with no wings or additions. Two bedrooms and an attic storeroom fitted up under the steeply sloped thatch. If the whitewash was all but gone from the stout wooden walls after the winter storms, the house was still in a tidy state of repair, the thatch tightly mended and the doors and shutters well-hung and snug-fitting.

haʊs, bɑɹn, ən stoʊn ʃip pɛn fɔɹm ðə pɔɪns ʌv ə tʃɹaɪæŋɡəl ɝaʊn ðə fɑɹmjɑɹd, wɛɹ ə fju tʃɪkənz hæd vɛntʃɝɾ aʊt tə skɹætʃ ət ðə koʊld ɡɹaʊnd. ən oʊpən ʃɪɹɪŋ ʃɛɾ ən ə stoʊn dɪpɪŋ tʃɹɔf stʊd nɛks tə ðə ʃip pɛn. hɑɹd baɪ ðə filz bɪtwin ðə fɑɹmjɑɹɾ ən ðə tʃɹiz lum ðə tɔl koʊn ʌv ə taɪt-wɔl kjʊɹɪŋ ʃɛd. fju fɑɹmɝz ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz kəd meɪk də wɪθaʊt boʊθ wʊl ən təbæk tə sɛl wən ðə mɝtʃəns keɪm.

House, barn, and stone sheep pen formed the points of a triangle around the farmyard, where a few chickens had ventured out to scratch at the cold ground. An open shearing shed and a stone dipping trough stood next to the sheep pen. Hard by the fields between the farmyard and the trees loomed the tall cone of a tight-walled curing shed. Few farmers in the Two Rivers could make do without both wool and tabac to sell when the merchants came.

wən ɹænd tʊk ə lʊk ɪn ðə stoʊn pɛn, ðə hɛvi-hɔɹn hɝd ɹæm lʊk bæk ət hɪm, bʌt moʊst ə ðə blæk-feɪs flɑk ɹɪmeɪn plɑtʃədli wɛɹ ðeɪ leɪ, əɹ stʊd wɪð ðɛɹ hɛdz ɪn ðə fid tʃɹɔf. ðɛɹ koʊts wɝ θɪk ən kɝli, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl tu koʊl fəɹ ʃɪɹɪŋ.

When Rand took a look in the stone pen, the heavy-horned herd ram looked back at him, but most of the black-faced flock remained placidly where they lay, or stood with their heads in the feed trough. Their coats were thick and curly, but it was still too cold for shearing.

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðə blæk-kloʊk mæn keɪm hɪɹ," ɹænd kɔl tə hɪz fɑðɝ, hu wɑz wɔkɪŋ sloʊli ɝaʊn ðə fɑɹmhaʊs, spɪɹ hɛld ət ðə ɹɛɾi, ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪntɛnli. "ðə ʃip wʊdn bi soʊ sɛɾəld ɪf ðət wʌn hæd bɪn ɝaʊnd."

"I don't think the black-cloaked man came here," Rand called to his father, who was walking slowly around the farmhouse, spear held at the ready, examining the ground intently. "The sheep wouldn't be so settled if that one had been around."

tæm nɑɾəd bʌt dɪd nɑt stɑp. wən i hæd meɪɾ ə kəmplit sɝkəɾ ə ðə haʊs, hi dɪd ðə seɪm ɝaʊn ðə bɑɹn ən ðə ʃip pɛn, stɪl stʌɾiɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi ivən tʃɛk ðə smoʊkhaʊs ən ðə kjʊɹɪŋ ʃɛd. dʒɹɔɪŋ ə bʌkəɾ ʌv wɔɾɝ fɹəm ðə wɛl, hi fɪld ə kʌp hænd, snɪf ðə wɔɾɝ, ən dʒɪnʒɝli tʌtʃt ɪt wɪð ðə tɪp ə hɪz tʌŋ. əbɹʌpli hi bɑɹkt ə læf, ðən dʒɹæŋk ɪt daʊn ɪn ə kwɪk ɡʌlp.

Tam nodded but did not stop. When he had made a complete circuit of the house, he did the same around the barn and the sheep pen, still studying the ground. He even checked the smokehouse and the curing shed. Drawing a bucket of water from the well, he filled a cupped hand, sniffed the water, and gingerly touched it with the tip of his tongue. Abruptly he barked a laugh, then drank it down in a quick gulp.

"aɪ səpoʊz i dɪdnt," hi toʊld ɹænd, waɪpɪŋ ɪz hæn ɑn ɪz koʊt fɹʌnt. "ɔl ðɪs əbaʊt mɛn ən hɔɹsəz aɪ kæn si əɹ hɪɹ dʒʌs meɪks mi lʊk kɹɔsweɪz əɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ." hi ɛmptid ðə wɛl wɔɾɝ ɪndə ənʌðɝ bʌkəɾ ən stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə haʊs, ðə bʌkəɾ ɪn wʌn hæn ən ɪz spɪɹ ɪn ði ʌðɝ. "aɪl stɑɹt səm stu fəɹ sʌpɝ. ən əz lɔŋ əz wɝ hɪɹ, wi maɪɾ əz wɛl ɡɛt kɑɾ ʌp ɑn ə fju tʃɔɹz."

"I suppose he didn't," he told Rand, wiping his hand on his coat front. "All this about men and horses I can't see or hear just makes me look crossways at everything." He emptied the well water into another bucket and started for the house, the bucket in one hand and his spear in the other. "I'll start some stew for supper. And as long as we're here, we might as well get caught up on a few chores."

ɹænd ɡɹɪməst, ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ wɪntɝnaɪɾ ɪn ɛmənz fild. bʌt tæm wɑz ɹaɪt. ɝaʊn ə fɑɹm ðə wɝk nɛvɝ ɹɪli ɡɑt dʌn; əz sun əz wʌn θɪŋ wɑz fɪnɪʃt tu mɔɹ ɔlweɪz niɾəd duɪŋ. hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd əbaʊɾ ɪt, bʌt kɛpt ɪz baʊ ən kwɪvɝ kloʊs ət hænd. ɪf ðə dɑɹk ɹaɪɾɝ dɪɾ əpɪɹ, hi hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə feɪsɪŋ ɪm wɪð nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ə hoʊ.

Rand grimaced, regretting Winternight in Emond's Field. But Tam was right. Around a farm the work never really got done; as soon as one thing was finished two more always needed doing. He hesitated about it, but kept his bow and quiver close at hand. If the dark rider did appear, he had no intention of facing him with nothing but a hoe.

fɝst wɑz stɑbəlɪŋ bɛlə. wʌns i hæɾ ənhɑɹnəst əɹ ən pʊɾ əɹ ɪndə ə stɔl ɪn ðə bɑɹn nɛks tə ðɛɹ kaʊ, hi sɛɾ ɪz kloʊk əsaɪɾ ən ɹʌb ðə mɛɹ daʊn wɪð hænfəlz ə dʒɹaɪ stʃɹɔ, ðən kɝiɾ əɹ wɪð ə pɛɹ ə bɹʌʃɪz. klaɪmɪŋ ðə nɛɹoʊ læɾɝ tə ðə lɔft, hi pɪtʃt daʊn heɪ fəɹ əɹ fid. hi fɛtʃt ə skupfəl ʌv oʊts fəɹ əɹ əz wɛl, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl ɪnʌf lɛft ən maɪt bi noʊ mɔɹ fəɹ ə lɔŋ waɪl ənlɛs ðə wɛðɝ wɔɹm sun. ðə kaʊ hæd bɪn mɪlk ðət mɔɹnɪŋ bɪfɔɹ fɝs laɪt, ɡɪvɪŋ ə kɔɹɾɝ ə hɝ juʒəwəl jild; ʃi sim tə bi dʒɹaɪɪŋ ʌp əz ðə wɪntɝ hʌŋ ɑn.

First was stabling Bela. Once he had unharnessed her and put her into a stall in the barn next to their cow, he set his cloak aside and rubbed the mare down with handfuls of dry straw, then curried her with a pair of brushes. Climbing the narrow ladder to the loft, he pitched down hay for her feed. He fetched a scoopful of oats for her as well, though there was little enough left and might be no more for a long while unless the weather warmed soon. The cow had been milked that morning before first light, giving a quarter of her usual yield; she seemed to be drying up as the winter hung on.

ɪnʌf fid hæd bɪn lɛf tə si ðə ʃip fəɹ tu deɪz - ðeɪ ʃʊɾə bɪn ɪn ðə pæstʃɝ baɪ naʊ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌn wɝθ kɔlɪŋ ɪt soʊ - bʌɾ i tɑpt ɔf ðɛɹ wɔɾɝ. wʌtɛvɝ ɛɡz hæd bɪn leɪd niɾəd tə bi ɡæðɝd, tu. ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli θɹi. ðə hɛnz sim tə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ klɛvɝɝ ət haɪɾɪŋ ðɛm.

Enough feed had been left to see the sheep for two days - they should have been in the pasture by now, but there was none worth calling it so - but he topped off their water. Whatever eggs had been laid needed to be gathered, too. There were only three. The hens seemed to be getting cleverer at hiding them.

hi wɑz teɪkɪŋ ə hoʊ tə ðə vɛdʒtəbəl ɡɑɹɾən bɪhaɪn ðə haʊs wən tæm keɪm aʊɾ ən sɛɾəld ɑn ə bɛntʃ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə bɑɹn tə mɛn hɑɹnəs, pɹɑpɪŋ ɪz spɪɹ bɪsaɪd hɪm. ɪt meɪd ɹænd fil bɛɾɝ əbaʊt ðə baʊ laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪz kloʊk ə peɪs fɹəm wɛɹ i stʊd.

He was taking a hoe to the vegetable garden behind the house when Tam came out and settled on a bench in front of the barn to mend harness, propping his spear beside him. It made Rand feel better about the bow lying on his cloak a pace from where he stood.

fju widz hæd pʊʃt əbʌv ɡɹaʊnd, bʌt mɔɹ widz ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. ðə kæbɪdʒɪz wɝ stʌntɪd, bɛɹli ə spɹaʊɾ ə ðə binz əɹ piz ʃoʊd, ən ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ə saɪn ʌv ə bit. nɑɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ hæd bɪn plæntəd, ʌv kɔɹs; oʊnli pɑɹt, ɪn hoʊps ðə koʊl maɪt bɹeɪk ɪn taɪm tə meɪk ə kɹɑp ə səm kaɪn bɪfɔɹ ðə sɛlɝ wɑz ɛmpti. ɪt dɪd nɑt teɪk lɔŋ tə fɪnɪʃ hoʊɪŋ, wɪtʃ wʊɾə suɾəd ɪm dʒʌs faɪn ɪn jɪɹz pæst, bʌt naʊ hi wʌndɝd wʌt ðeɪ wəd də ɪf nʌθɪŋ keɪm ʌp ðɪs jɪɹ. nɑɾ ə plɛzən θɔt. ən ðəɹ wɑz stɪl faɪɝwʊd tə splɪt.

Few weeds had pushed above ground, but more weeds than anything else. The cabbages were stunted, barely a sprout of the beans or peas showed, and there was not a sign of a beet. Not everything had been planted, of course; only part, in hopes the cold might break in time to make a crop of some kind before the cellar was empty. It did not take long to finish hoeing, which would have suited him just fine in years past, but now he wondered what they would do if nothing came up this year. Not a pleasant thought. And there was still firewood to split.

ɪt sim tə ɹænd laɪk jɪɹz sɪns ðəɹ hæd nɑt bɪn faɪɝwʊd tə splɪt. bʌt kəmpleɪnɪŋ wəd nɑt kip ðə haʊs wɔɹm, soʊ hi fɛtʃt ði æks, pɹɑpt ʌp baʊ ən kwɪvɝ bɪsaɪd ðə tʃɑpɪŋ blɑk, ən ɡɑt tə wɝk. paɪn fəɹ ə kwɪk, hɑt fleɪm, ən oʊk fəɹ lɔŋ bɝnɪŋ. bɪfɔɹ lɔŋ i wɑz wɔɹm ɪnʌf tə pʊɾ ɪz koʊɾ əsaɪd. wən ðə paɪl ə splɪt wʊd ɡɹu bɪɡ ɪnʌf, hi stækt ɪɾ əɡɛns ðə saɪɾ ə ðə haʊs, bɪsaɪɾ ʌðɝ stæks ɔlɹɛɾi ðɛɹ. moʊst ɹitʃt ɔl ðə weɪ tə ði ivz. juʒəwəli baɪ ðɪs taɪm ə jɪɹ ðə wʊdpəlz wɝ smɔl ən fju, bʌt nɑt ðɪs jɪɹ. tʃɑp ən stæk, tʃɑp ən stæk, hi lɔs hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðə ɹɪðəm ə ði æks ən ðə moʊʃənz ə stækɪŋ wʊd. tæmz hæn ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ bɹɔɾ ɪm bæk tə wɛɹ i wɑz, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən i blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz.

It seemed to Rand like years since there had not been firewood to split. But complaining would not keep the house warm, so he fetched the axe, propped up bow and quiver beside the chopping block, and got to work. Pine for a quick, hot flame, and oak for long burning. Before long he was warm enough to put his coat aside. When the pile of split wood grew big enough, he stacked it against the side of the house, beside other stacks already there. Most reached all the way to the eaves. Usually by this time of year the woodpiles were small and few, but not this year. Chop and stack, chop and stack, he lost himself in the rhythm of the axe and the motions of stacking wood. Tam's hand on his shoulder brought him back to where he was, and for a moment he blinked in surprise.

ɡɹeɪ twaɪlaɪt hæd kʌm ɑn waɪl i wɝkt, ən ɔlɹɛɾi ɪt wɑz feɪɾɪŋ kwɪkli təwɔɹd naɪt. ðə fʊl mun stʊd wɛl əbʌv ðə tʃɹitɑps, ʃɪmɝɪŋ peɪl ən bʌlʒɪŋ əz ɪf əbaʊt tə fɔl ɑn ðɛɹ hɛdz. ðə wɪn hæd ɡɹoʊn koʊldɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɪz noʊɾɪsɪŋ, tu, ən tæɾɝd klaʊdz skʌɾɪd əkɹɔs ðə dɑɹklɪŋ skaɪ.

Gray twilight had come on while he worked, and already it was fading quickly toward night. The full moon stood well above the treetops, shimmering pale and bulging as if about to fall on their heads. The wind had grown colder without his noticing, too, and tattered clouds scudded across the darkling sky.

"lɛts wɑʃ ʌp, læd, ən si əbaʊt səm sʌpɝ. aɪv ɔlɹɛɾi kæɹiɾ ɪn wɔɾɝ fəɹ hɑt bæθs bɪfɔɹ slip."

"Let's wash up, lad, and see about some supper. I've already carried in water for hot baths before sleep."

"ɛniθɪŋ hɑt saʊnz ɡʊd tə mi," ɹænd sɛd, snætʃɪŋ ʌp ɪz kloʊk ən tɔsɪŋ ɪt ɹaʊn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. swɛt soʊkt ɪz ʃɝt, ən ðə wɪnd, fɝɡɑɾən ɪn ðə hiɾ ə swɪŋɪŋ ði æks, sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɹiz ɪt naʊ ðəɾ i hæd stɑpt wɝk. hi staɪfəld ə jɔn, ʃɪvɝɪŋ əz i ɡæðɝd ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz θɪŋz. "æn slip, tu, fəɹ ðæt. aɪ maɪt dʒʌst slip ɹaɪt θɹu fɛstəvəl."

"Anything hot sounds good to me," Rand said, snatching up his cloak and tossing it round his shoulders. Sweat soaked his shirt, and the wind, forgotten in the heat of swinging the axe, seemed to be trying to freeze it now that he had stopped work. He stifled a yawn, shivering as he gathered the rest of his things. "And sleep, too, for that. I might just sleep right through Festival."

"wʊd jə kɛɹ tə meɪk ə smɔl weɪdʒɝ əbaʊt ðæt?" tæm smaɪld, ən ɹænd hæd tə ɡɹɪn bæk. hi wəd nɑt mɪs bɛl taɪn ɪf i hæd hæd noʊ slip ɪn ə wik. noʊ wʌn wʊd.

"Would you care to make a small wager about that?" Tam smiled, and Rand had to grin back. He would not miss Bel Tine if he had had no sleep in a week. No one would.

tæm hæd bɪn ɪkstʃɹævəɡənt wɪð ðə kændəlz, ən ə faɪɝ kɹækəld ɪn ðə bɪɡ stoʊn faɪɝpleɪs, soʊ ðət ðə meɪn ɹum hæɾ ə wɔɹm, tʃɪɹfəl fil tə ɪt. ə bɹɔɾ oʊeɪkən teɪbəl wɑz ðə meɪn fitʃɝ ə ðə ɹum ʌðɝ ðən ðə faɪɝpleɪs, ə teɪbəl lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə siɾ ə dʌzən əɹ mɔɹ, ðoʊ ðəɹ hæd sɛldəm bɪn soʊ mɛni ɝaʊn ɪt sɪns ɹændz mʌðɝ daɪd. ə fju kæbənəts ən tʃɛsts, moʊst ə ðɛm skɪlfəli meɪd baɪ tæm hɪmsɛlf, laɪn ðə wɔlz, ən haɪ-bæk tʃɛɹz stʊɾ ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl. ðə kʊʃən tʃɛɹ ðət tæm kɔld ɪz ɹiɾɪŋ tʃɛɹ sæɾ æŋɡəl bɪfɔɹ ðə fleɪmz. ɹænd pɹəfɝd tə də hɪz ɹiɾɪŋ stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ɑn ðə ɹʌɡ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝ. ðə ʃɛlf ə bʊks baɪ ðə dɔɹ wɑz nɑt nɪɹli əz lɔŋ əz ðə wʌn ət ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn, bʌt bʊks wɝ hɑɹd tə kʌm baɪ. fju pɛdlɝz kæɹid mɔɹ ðən ə hændfʊl, ən ðoʊz hæd tə bi stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ əmʌŋ ɛvɹiwʌn u wɑntəd ðɛm.

Tam had been extravagant with the candles, and a fire crackled in the big stone fireplace, so that the main room had a warm, cheerful feel to it. A broad oaken table was the main feature of the room other than the fireplace, a table long enough to seat a dozen or more, though there had seldom been so many around it since Rand's mother died. A few cabinets and chests, most of them skillfully made by Tam himself, lined the walls, and high-backed chairs stood around the table. The cushioned chair that Tam called his reading chair sat angled before the flames. Rand preferred to do his reading stretched out on the rug in front of the fire. The shelf of books by the door was not nearly as long as the one at the Winespring Inn, but books were hard to come by. Few peddlers carried more than a handful, and those had to be stretched out among everyone who wanted them.

ɪf ðə ɹum dɪd nɑt lʊk kwaɪt soʊ fɹɛʃli skɹʌbd əz moʊs fɑɹm waɪvz kɛp ðɛɹ hoʊmz - tæmz paɪpɝæk ən ðə tʃɹævəlz ə dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ sæɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl, waɪl ənʌðɝ wʊd-baʊn bʊk ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ðə kʊʃən ə hɪz ɹiɾɪŋ tʃɛɹ; ə bɪɾ ə hɑɹnəs tə bi mɛndɪd leɪ ɑn ðə bɛntʃ baɪ ðə faɪɝpleɪs, ən səm ʃɝts tə bi dɑɹn meɪɾ ə hip ɑn ə tʃɛɹ - ɪf nɑt kwaɪt soʊ spɑtləs, ɪt wɑz stɪl klin ən niɾ ɪnʌf, wɪð ə lɪvd-ɪn lʊk ðət wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz wɔɹmɪŋ ən kʌmfɝɾɪŋ əz ðə faɪɝ. hɪɹ, ɪt wɑz pɑsəbəl tə fɝɡɛt ðə tʃɪl bɪɑn ðə wɔlz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ fɔls dʒɹæɡən hɪɹ. noʊ wɔɹz əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. noʊ mɛn ɪn blæk kloʊks. ði ɝoʊmə fɹəm ðə stupɑt hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə faɪɝ pɝmieɪɾɪd ðə ɹum, ən fɪld ɹænd wɪð ɹævənəs hʌŋɡɝ.

If the room did not look quite so freshly scrubbed as most farm wives kept their homes - Tam's piperack and The Travels of Jain Farstrider sat on the table, while another wood-bound book rested on the cushion of his reading chair; a bit of harness to be mended lay on the bench by the fireplace, and some shirts to be darned made a heap on a chair - if not quite so spotless, it was still clean and neat enough, with a lived-in look that was almost as warming and comforting as the fire. Here, it was possible to forget the chill beyond the walls. There was no false Dragon here. No wars or Aes Sedai. No men in black cloaks. The aroma from the stewpot hanging over the fire permeated the room, and filled Rand with ravenous hunger.

hɪz fɑðɝ stɝd ðə stupɑt wɪð ə lɔŋ-hændəld wʊɾən spun, ðən tʊk ə teɪst. "ə lɪɾəl waɪl lɔŋɡɝ."

His father stirred the stewpot with a long-handled wooden spoon, then took a taste. "A little while longer."

ɹænd hɝid tə wɑʃ ɪz feɪs ən hænz; ðəɹ wɑz ə pɪtʃɝ ən beɪsən ɑn ðə wɑʃstæn baɪ ðə dɔɹ. ə hɑt bæθ wɑz wʌɾ i wɑntəd, tə teɪk əweɪ ðə swɛɾ ən soʊk ðə tʃɪl aʊt, bʌt ðət wəd kʌm wən ðəɹ hæd bɪn taɪm tə hit ðə bɪɡ kɛɾəl ɪn ðə bæk ɹum.

Rand hurried to wash his face and hands; there was a pitcher and basin on the washstand by the door. A hot bath was what he wanted, to take away the sweat and soak the chill out, but that would come when there had been time to heat the big kettle in the back room.

tæm ɹuɾəd ɝaʊn ɪn ə kæbənəɾ ən keɪm ʌp wɪð ə ki əz lɔŋ əz ɪz hænd. hi twɪstəɾ ɪɾ ɪn ðə bɪɡ aɪɝn lɑk ɑn ðə dɔɹ. ət ɹændz kwɛstʃənɪŋ lʊk i sɛd, "bɛs tə bi seɪf. meɪbi aɪm teɪkɪŋ ə fænsi, əɹ meɪbi ðə wɛðɝ ɪz blækɪŋ maɪ mud, bʌt. . . ." hi saɪɾ ən baʊns ðə ki ɑn ɪz pɑm. "aɪl si tə ðə bæk dɔɹ," hi sɛd, ən dɪsəpɪɹd təwɔɹd ðə bæk ə ðə haʊs.

Tam rooted around in a cabinet and came up with a key as long as his hand. He twisted it in the big iron lock on the door. At Rand's questioning look he said, "Best to be safe. Maybe I'm taking a fancy, or maybe the weather is blacking my mood, but. . . ." He sighed and bounced the key on his palm. "I'll see to the back door," he said, and disappeared toward the back of the house.

ɹænd kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ iðɝ dɔɹ ɛvɝ biɪŋ lɑkt. noʊ wʌn ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz lɑk dɔɹz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid. əntɪl naʊ, ət list.

Rand could not remember either door ever being locked. No one in the Two Rivers locked doors. There was no need. Until now, at least.

fɹəm oʊvɝhɛd, fɹəm tæmz bɛdʒɹum, keɪm ə skɹeɪpɪŋ, əz ə sʌmθɪŋ biɪŋ dʒɹæɡd əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ. ɹænd fɹaʊnd. ənlɛs tæm hæd sʌɾənli dɪsaɪɾɪd tə muv ðə fɝnɪtʃɝ ɝaʊnd, hi kəɾ oʊnli bi pʊlɪŋ aʊt ði oʊl tʃɛst i kɛpt ʌndɝ ɪz bɛd. ənʌðɝ θɪŋ ðət hæd nɛvɝ bɪn dʌn ɪn ɹændz mɛmɹi.

From overhead, from Tam's bedroom, came a scraping, as of something being dragged across the floor. Rand frowned. Unless Tam had suddenly decided to move the furniture around, he could only be pulling out the old chest he kept under his bed. Another thing that had never been done in Rand's memory.

hi fɪld ə smɔl kɛɾəl wɪð wɔɾɝ fəɹ ti ən hʌŋ ɪt fɹəm ə hʊk oʊvɝ ðə faɪɝ, ðən sɛt ðə teɪbəl. hi hæd kɑɹv ðə boʊlz ən spunz hɪmsɛlf. ðə fɹʌnt ʃʌɾɝz hæd nɑt jɛt bɪn kloʊzd, ən fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm i pɪɹɾ aʊt, bʌt fʊl naɪt hæd kʌm ən ɔl i kəd si wɝ mun ʃædoʊz. ðə dɑɹk ɹaɪɾɝ kəd bi aʊt ðəɹ izəli ɪnʌf, bʌɾ i tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðæt.

He filled a small kettle with water for tea and hung it from a hook over the fire, then set the table. He had carved the bowls and spoons himself. The front shutters had not yet been closed, and from time to time he peered out, but full night had come and all he could see were moon shadows. The dark rider could be out there easily enough, but he tried not to think about that.

wən tæm keɪm bæk, ɹænd stɛɹɾ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. ə θɪk bɛl slæntəɾ ɝaʊn tæmz weɪst, ən fɹəm ðə bɛl hʌŋ ə sɔɹd, wɪð ə bɹɑnz hɛɹən ɑn ðə blæk skæbɝɾ ən ənʌðɝ ɑn ðə lɔŋ hɪlt. ði oʊnli mɛn ɹænd hæɾ ɛvɝ sin wɛɹɪŋ sɔɹdz wɝ ðə mɝtʃəns' ɡɑɹdz. ən læn, ʌv kɔɹs. ðəɾ ɪz fɑðɝ maɪɾ oʊn wʌn hæd nɛvɝ ivən əkɝd tə hɪm. ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə hɛɹənz, ðə sɔɹd lʊkt ə ɡʊd dil laɪk lænz sɔɹd.

When Tam came back, Rand stared in surprise. A thick belt slanted around Tam's waist, and from the belt hung a sword, with a bronze heron on the black scabbard and another on the long hilt. The only men Rand had ever seen wearing swords were the merchants' guards. And Lan, of course. That his father might own one had never even occurred to him. Except for the herons, the sword looked a good deal like Lan's sword.

"wɛɹ dɪd ðət kʌm fɹʌm?" hi æskt. "dɪd jə ɡɛɾ ɪt fɹəm ə pɛdlɝ? haʊ mʌtʃ dɪɾ ɪt kɑst?"

"Where did that come from?" he asked. "Did you get it from a peddler? How much did it cost?"

sloʊli tæm dʒɹu ðə wɛpən; faɪɹlaɪt pleɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə ɡlimɪŋ lɛŋθ. ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl laɪk ðə pleɪn, ɹʌf bleɪdz ɹænd hæd sin ɪn ðə hænz ə mɝtʃəns' ɡɑɹdz. noʊ dʒɛmz əɹ ɡoʊld ədɔɹn ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt simd ɡɹæn tə hɪm, nʌnðəlɛs. ðə bleɪd, vɛɹi slaɪtli kɝvd ən ʃɑɹp ɑn oʊnli wʌn ɛdʒ, bɔɹ ənʌðɝ hɛɹən ɛtʃt ɪndə ðə stil. ʃɔɹt kwɪlənz, wɝk tə lʊk laɪk bɹeɪd, flæŋk ðə hɪlt. ɪt simd ɔlmoʊs fɹædʒəl kəmpɛɹd wɪð ðə sɔɹdz ə ðə mɝtʃəns' ɡɑɹdz; moʊst ə ðoʊz wɝ dʌbəl-ɛdʒd, ən θɪk ɪnʌf tə tʃɑp daʊn ə tʃɹi.

Slowly Tam drew the weapon; firelight played along the gleaming length. It was nothing at all like the plain, rough blades Rand had seen in the hands of merchants' guards. No gems or gold adorned it, but it seemed grand to him, nonetheless. The blade, very slightly curved and sharp on only one edge, bore another heron etched into the steel. Short quillons, worked to look like braid, flanked the hilt. It seemed almost fragile compared with the swords of the merchants' guards; most of those were double-edged, and thick enough to chop down a tree.

"aɪ ɡɑɾ ɪɾ ə lɔŋ taɪm əɡoʊ," tæm sɛd, "ə lɔŋ weɪ fɹəm hɪɹ. ən aɪ peɪɾ ɪntaɪɝli tu mʌtʃ; tu kɑpɝz ɪz tu mʌtʃ fəɹ wʌn ə ðiz. jəɹ mʌðɝ dɪdn əpɹuv, bʌt ʃi wɑz ɔlweɪz waɪzɝ ðən aɪ. aɪ wɑz jʌŋ ðɛn, ən ɪt simd wɝθ ðə pɹaɪs ət ðə taɪm. ʃi ɔlweɪz wɑntəd mi tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ʌv ɪt, ən mɔɹ ðən wʌns aɪv θɔt ʃi wɑz ɹaɪt, ðəɾ aɪ ʃəd dʒʌst ɡɪv ɪɾ əweɪ."

"I got it a long time ago," Tam said, "a long way from here. And I paid entirely too much; two coppers is too much for one of these. Your mother didn't approve, but she was always wiser than I. I was young then, and it seemed worth the price at the time. She always wanted me to get rid of it, and more than once I've thought she was right, that I should just give it away."

ɹəflɛktəd faɪɝ meɪd ðə bleɪd sim əfleɪm. ɹænd stɑɹɾəd. hi hæɾ ɔfən deɪdʒɹimd əbaʊɾ oʊnɪŋ ə sɔɹd. "ɡɪv ɪɾ əweɪ? haʊ kəd jə ɡɪv ə sɔɹd laɪk ðəɾ əweɪ?"

Reflected fire made the blade seem aflame. Rand started. He had often daydreamed about owning a sword. "Give it away? How could you give a sword like that away?"

tæm snɔɹɾɪd. "nɑt mʌtʃ jus ɪn hɝɾɪŋ ʃip, naʊ ɪz ɪt? kæn plaʊ ə fild əɹ hɑɹvəst ə kɹɑp wɪð ɪt." fəɹ ə lɔŋ mɪnəɾ i stɛɹɾ ət ðə sɔɹɾ əz ɪf wʌndɝɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ wɪð sətʃ ə θɪŋ. ət læst i lɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɛvi saɪ. "bʌɾ ɪf aɪm nɑt dʒʌs teɪkən baɪ ə blæk fænsi, ɪf əɹ lʌk ɹʌnz saʊɝ, meɪbi ɪn ðə nɛks fju deɪz wɪl bi ɡlæɾ aɪ tʌkt ɪɾ ɪn ðəɾ oʊl tʃɛst, ɪnstɛd." hi slɪd ðə sɔɹd smuðli bæk ɪndə ɪts ʃiθ ən waɪpt ɪz hæn ɑn ɪz ʃɝt wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs. "ðə stu ʃəd bi ɹɛɾi. əl dɪʃ ɪɾ aʊt waɪl jə fɪks ðə ti."

Tam snorted. "Not much use in herding sheep, now is it? Can't plow a field or harvest a crop with it." For a long minute he stared at the sword as if wondering what he was doing with such a thing. At last he let out a heavy sigh. "But if I am not just taken by a black fancy, if our luck runs sour, maybe in the next few days we'll be glad I tucked it in that old chest, instead." He slid the sword smoothly back into its sheath and wiped his hand on his shirt with a grimace. "The stew should be ready. I'll dish it out while you fix the tea."

ɹænd nɑɾəd ən ɡɑt ðə ti kænəstɝ, bʌɾ i wɑntəd tə noʊ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. waɪ wəd tæm əv bɑɾ ə sɔɹd? hi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən. ən wɛɹ hæd tæm kʌm baɪ ɪt? haʊ fɑɹ əweɪ? noʊ wʌn ɛvɝ lɛf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz; əɹ vɛɹi fju, ət list. hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz veɪɡli səpoʊzd ɪz fɑðɝ mʌst əv ɡɔn aʊtsaɪd - hɪz mʌðɝ hæd bɪn ən aʊtləndɝ - bʌɾ ə sɔɹd . . . ? hi hæɾ ə lɑɾ ə kwɛstʃənz tə æsk wʌns ðeɪ hæd sɛɾəld ət ðə teɪbəl.

Rand nodded and got the tea canister, but he wanted to know everything. Why would Tam have bought a sword? He could not imagine. And where had Tam come by it? How far away? No one ever left the Two Rivers; or very few, at least. He had always vaguely supposed his father must have gone outside - his mother had been an outlander - but a sword . . . ? He had a lot of questions to ask once they had settled at the table.

ðə ti wɔɾɝ wɑz bɔɪlɪŋ fɪɹsli, ən i hæd tə ɹæp ə klɔθ ɝaʊn ðə kɛɾəlz hændəl tə lɪft ɪɾ ɔf ðə hʊk. hit soʊk θɹu ɪmiɾiətli. əz i stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm ðə faɪɝ, ə hɛvi θʌmp ət ðə dɔɹ ɹæɾəld ðə lɑk. ɔl θɔts ə ðə sɔɹd, əɹ ðə hɑt kɛɾəl ɪn ɪz hænd, flu əweɪ.

The tea water was boiling fiercely, and he had to wrap a cloth around the kettle's handle to lift it off the hook. Heat soaked through immediately. As he straightened from the fire, a heavy thump at the door rattled the lock. All thoughts of the sword, or the hot kettle in his hand, flew away.

"wʌn ə ðə neɪbɝz," hi sɛɾ ənsɝteɪnli. "mæstɝ daʊtʃɹi wɑntɪŋ tə bɑɹoʊ. . . ." bʌt ðə daʊtʃɹi fɑɹm, ðɛɹ nɪɹəs neɪbɝ, wɑz ən aʊɝ əweɪ ivən ɪn ðə deɪlaɪt, ən ɔɹən daʊtʃɹi, ʃeɪmləs bɑɹoʊɝ ðəɾ i wɑz, wɑz stɪl nɑt laɪkli tə liv ɪz haʊs baɪ dɑɹk.

"One of the neighbors," he said uncertainly. "Master Dautry wanting to borrow. . . ." But the Dautry farm, their nearest neighbor, was an hour away even in the daylight, and Oren Dautry, shameless borrower that he was, was still not likely to leave his house by dark.

tæm sɔfli pleɪs ðə stu-fɪl boʊlz ɑn ðə teɪbəl. sloʊli hi muvd əweɪ fɹəm ðə teɪbəl. boʊθ ə hɪz hænz ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk - " hi bɪɡæn, ən ðə dɔɹ bɝst oʊpən, pisəz ə ði aɪɝn lɑk spɪnɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ.

Tam softly placed the stew-filled bowls on the table. Slowly he moved away from the table. Both of his hands rested on his sword hilt. "I don't think - " he began, and the door burst open, pieces of the iron lock spinning across the floor.

ə fɪɡjɝ fɪl ðə dɔɹweɪ, bɪɡɝ ðən ɛni mæn ɹænd hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, ə fɪɡjɝ ɪn blæk meɪl ðət hʌŋ tə hɪz niz, wɪð spaɪks ət ɹɪsts ən ɛlboʊz ən ʃoʊldɝz. wʌn hæn klʌtʃt ə hɛvi, saɪð-laɪk sɔɹd; ði ʌðɝ hænd wɑz flʌŋ ʌp bɪfɔɹ ɪz aɪz əz ɪf tə ʃild əm fɹəm ðə laɪt.

A figure filled the doorway, bigger than any man Rand had ever seen, a figure in black mail that hung to his knees, with spikes at wrists and elbows and shoulders. One hand clutched a heavy, scythe-like sword; the other hand was flung up before his eyes as if to shield them from the light.

ɹænd fɛl ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋz ʌv ən ɑd sɔɹɾ ə ɹɪlif. huɛvɝ ðɪs wɑz, ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə blæk-kloʊkt ɹaɪɾɝ. ðən i sɔ ðə kɝld ɹæmz hɔɹnz ɑn ðə hɛd ðət bɹʌʃt ðə tɑp ə ðə dɔɹweɪ, ən wɛɹ maʊθ ən noʊz ʃʊɾə bɪn wɑz ə hɛɹi mʌzəl. hi tʊk ɪn ɔl ʌv ɪɾ ɪn ðə speɪs ʌv wʌn dip bɹɛθ ðəɾ i lɛɾ aʊɾ ɪn ə tɛɹəfaɪd jɛl æz, wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ, hi hɝl ðə hɑt kɛɾəl ət ðət hæf-hjumən hɛd.

Rand felt the beginnings of an odd sort of relief. Whoever this was, it was not the black-cloaked rider. Then he saw the curled ram's horns on the head that brushed the top of the doorway, and where mouth and nose should have been was a hairy muzzle. He took in all of it in the space of one deep breath that he let out in a terrified yell as, without thinking, he hurled the hot kettle at that half-human head.

ðə kɹitʃɝ ɹɔɹd, pɑɹt skɹim ə peɪn, pɑɹɾ ænəməl snɑɹl, əz bɔɪlɪŋ wɔɾɝ splæʃt oʊvɝ ɪts feɪs. ivən əz ðə kɛɾəl stʃɹʌk, tæmz sɔɹd flæʃt. ðə ɹɔɹ əbɹʌpli bɪkeɪm ə ɡɝɡəl, ən ðə hjudʒ ʃeɪp tɑpəl bæk. bɪfɔɹ ɪt fɪnɪʃt fɔlɪŋ, ənʌðɝ wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə klɔ ɪts weɪ pæst. ɹænd ɡlɪmpst ə mɪsʃeɪpən hɛd tɑp baɪ spaɪk-laɪk hɔɹnz bɪfɔɹ tæm stʃɹʌk əɡɛn, ən tu hjudʒ bɑɾiz blɑk ðə dɔɹ. hi ɹilaɪzd ɪz fɑðɝ wɑz ʃaʊɾɪŋ ət hɪm.

The creature roared, part scream of pain, part animal snarl, as boiling water splashed over its face. Even as the kettle struck, Tam's sword flashed. The roar abruptly became a gurgle, and the huge shape toppled back. Before it finished falling, another was trying to claw its way past. Rand glimpsed a misshapen head topped by spike-like horns before Tam struck again, and two huge bodies blocked the door. He realized his father was shouting at him.

"ɹʌn, læd! haɪɾ ɪn ðə wʊdz!" ðə bɑɾiz ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ dʒɝkt əz ʌðɝz aʊtsaɪd tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl əm klɪɹ. tæm θɹʌst ə ʃoʊldɝ ʌndɝ ðə mæsɪv teɪbəl; wɪð ə ɡɹʌn i hivd ɪɾ oʊvɝ ətɑp ðə tæŋɡəl. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ tu mɛni tə hoʊld! aʊt ðə bæk! ɡoʊ! ɡoʊ! əl fɑloʊ!"

"Run, lad! Hide in the woods!" The bodies in the doorway jerked as others outside tried to pull them clear. Tam thrust a shoulder under the massive table; with a grunt he heaved it over atop the tangle. "There are too many to hold! Out the back! Go! Go! I'll follow!"

ivən əz ɹænd tɝn əweɪ, ʃeɪm fɪld ɪm ðəɾ i oʊbeɪd soʊ kwɪkli. hi wɑntəd tə steɪ ən hɛlp ɪz fɑðɝ, ðoʊ hi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən haʊ, bʌt fɪɹ hæɾ ɪm baɪ ðə θɹoʊt, ən ɪz lɛɡz muvd ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn. hi dæʃt fɹəm ðə ɹum, təwɔɹd ðə bæk ə ðə haʊs, əz fæst əz i hæɾ ɛvɝ ɹʌn ɪn ɪz laɪf. kɹæʃɪz ən ʃaʊts fɹəm ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ pɝsud hɪm.

Even as Rand turned away, shame filled him that he obeyed so quickly. He wanted to stay and help his father, though he could not imagine how, but fear had him by the throat, and his legs moved on their own. He dashed from the room, toward the back of the house, as fast as he had ever run in his life. Crashes and shouts from the front door pursued him.

hi hæɾ ɪz hænz ɑn ðə bɑɹ əkɹɔs ðə bæk dɔɹ wən ɪz aɪ fɛl ɑn ði aɪɝn lɑk ðət wɑz nɛvɝ lɑkt. ɪksɛp ðət tæm hæd dʌn dʒʌs ðət tənaɪt. lɛɾɪŋ ðə bɑɹ steɪ wɛɹ ɪt wɑz, hi dɑɹɾɪd tə ə saɪd wɪndoʊ, flʌŋ ʌp ðə sæʃ ən θɹu bæk ðə ʃʌɾɝz. naɪt hæd ɹipleɪs twaɪlaɪt kəmplitli. ðə fʊl mun ən dʒɹɪftɪŋ klaʊdz meɪd dæpəld ʃædoʊz tʃeɪs wʌn ənʌðɝ əkɹɔs ðə fɑɹmjɑɹd.

He had his hands on the bar across the back door when his eye fell on the iron lock that was never locked. Except that Tam had done just that tonight. Letting the bar stay where it was, he darted to a side window, flung up the sash and threw back the shutters. Night had replaced twilight completely. The full moon and drifting clouds made dappled shadows chase one another across the farmyard.

ʃædoʊz, hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf. oʊnli ʃædoʊz. ðə bæk dɔɹ kɹikt əz sʌmwʌn aʊtsaɪd, əɹ sʌmθɪŋ, tʃɹaɪd tə pʊʃ ɪɾ oʊpən. hɪz maʊθ wɛn dʒɹaɪ. ə kɹæʃ ʃʊk ðə dɔɹ ɪn ɪts fɹeɪm ən lɛn ɪm spid; hi slɪp θɹu ðə wɪndoʊ laɪk ə hɛɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɡɹaʊnd, ən kaʊɝɾ əɡɛns ðə saɪɾ ə ðə haʊs. ɪnsaɪd ðə ɹum, wʊd splɪntɝd laɪk θʌndɝ.

Shadows, he told himself. Only shadows. The back door creaked as someone outside, or something, tried to push it open. His mouth went dry. A crash shook the door in its frame and lent him speed; he slipped through the window like a hare going to ground, and cowered against the side of the house. Inside the room, wood splintered like thunder.

hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf ʌp tə ə kɹaʊtʃ, meɪd hɪmsɛlf pɪɹ ɪnsaɪd, dʒʌst wɪð wʌn aɪ, dʒʌst ət ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə wɪndoʊ. ɪn ðə dɑɹk i kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt mʌtʃ, bʌt mɔɹ ðən i ɹɪli wɑntəd tə si. ðə dɔɹ hʌŋ əskju, ən ʃæɾoʊd ʃeɪps muv kɔʃəsli ɪndə ðə ɹum, tɔkɪŋ ɪn loʊ, ɡʌɾɝəl vɔɪsəz. ɹænd ʌndɝstʊd nʌn ʌv wʌt wɑz sɛd; ðə læŋɡwədʒ saʊndəd hɑɹʃ, ənsuɾɪd tə ə hjumən tʌŋ. æksiz ən spɪɹz ən spaɪk θɪŋz dʌli ɹəflɛktəd stʃɹeɪ ɡlɪmɝz ə munlaɪt. buts skɹeɪpt ɑn ðə flɔɹ, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹɪðmɪk klɪk, əz ə hʊvz, əz wɛl.

He forced himself up to a crouch, made himself peer inside, just with one eye, just at the corner of the window. In the dark he could not make out much, but more than he really wanted to see. The door hung askew, and shadowed shapes moved cautiously into the room, talking in low, guttural voices. Rand understood none of what was said; the language sounded harsh, unsuited to a human tongue. Axes and spears and spiked things dully reflected stray glimmers of moonlight. Boots scraped on the floor, and there was a rhythmic click, as of hooves, as well.

hi tʃɹaɪd tə wɝk mɔɪstʃɝ bæk ɪndə hɪz maʊθ. dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip, ɹæɡəd bɹɛθ, hi ʃaʊɾəd əz laʊdli əz i kʊd. "ðeɪɹ kʌmɪŋ ɪn ðə bæk!" ðə wɝdz keɪm aʊɾ ɪn ə kɹoʊk, bʌɾ ət lis ðeɪ keɪm aʊt. hi hæd nɑt bɪn ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wʊd. "ɪm aʊtsaɪd! ɹʌn, fɑðɝ!" wɪð ðə læst wɝɾ i wɑz spɹɪntɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə fɑɹmhaʊs.

He tried to work moisture back into his mouth. Drawing a deep, ragged breath, he shouted as loudly as he could. "They're coming in the back!" The words came out in a croak, but at least they came out. He had not been sure they would. "I'm outside! Run, father!" With the last word he was sprinting away from the farmhouse.

kɔɹs-vɔɪst ʃaʊts ɪn ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ tʌŋ ɹeɪdʒ fɹəm ðə bæk ɹum. ɡlæs ʃæɾɝd, laʊɾ ən ʃɑɹp, ən sʌmθɪŋ θʌddɪd hɛvəli tə ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪhaɪn hɪm. hi ɡɛst wʌn ə ðɛm hæd bɹoʊkən θɹu ðə wɪndoʊ ɹæðɝ ðən tʃɹaɪ tə skwiz θɹu ði oʊpənɪŋ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt lʊk bæk tə si ɪf i wɑz ɹaɪt. laɪk ə fɑks ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm haʊnz i dɑɹɾɪd ɪndə ðə nɪɹəs mun-kæst ʃædoʊz əz ɪf hɛɾəd fəɹ ðə wʊdz, ðən dʒɹɑp tə hɪz bɛli ən slaɪðɝd bæk tə ðə bɑɹn ən ɪts lɑɹdʒɝ, dipɝ ʃædoʊz. sʌmθɪŋ fɛl əkɹɔs ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, ən i θɹæʃt əbaʊt, nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf i wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪɾ əɹ ɪskeɪp, əntɪl i ɹilaɪzd i wɑz ɡɹæplɪŋ wɪð ðə nu hoʊ hændəl tæm hæd bɪn ʃeɪpɪŋ.

Coarse-voiced shouts in the strange tongue raged from the back room. Glass shattered, loud and sharp, and something thudded heavily to the ground behind him. He guessed one of them had broken through the window rather than try to squeeze through the opening, but he did not look back to see if he was right. Like a fox running from hounds he darted into the nearest moon-cast shadows as if headed for the woods, then dropped to his belly and slithered back to the barn and its larger, deeper shadows. Something fell across his shoulders, and he thrashed about, not sure if he was trying to fight or escape, until he realized he was grappling with the new hoe handle Tam had been shaping.

ɪɾiət! fəɹ ə moʊmən i leɪ ðɛɹ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stɑp pæntɪŋ. kɑplɪn ful ɪɾiət! ət læst i kɹɔld ɑn əlɔŋ ðə bæk ə ðə bɑɹn, dʒɹæɡɪŋ ðə hoʊ hændəl wɪð hɪm. ɪt wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən nʌθɪŋ. kɔʃəsli hi lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹnɝ ət ðə fɑɹmjɑɹɾ ən ðə haʊs.

Idiot! For a moment he lay there, trying to stop panting. Coplin fool idiot! At last he crawled on along the back of the barn, dragging the hoe handle with him. It was not much, but it was better than nothing. Cautiously he looked around the corner at the farmyard and the house.

ʌv ðə kɹitʃɝ ðət hæd dʒʌmpt aʊɾ æftɝ ɪm ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn. ɪt kəd bi ɛniwɛɹ. hʌntɪŋ hɪm, ʃʊɹli. ivən kɹipɪŋ ʌp ɑn ɪm ət ðət vɛɹi moʊmənt.

Of the creature that had jumped out after him there was no sign. It could be anywhere. Hunting him, surely. Even creeping up on him at that very moment.

fɹaɪɾənd blits fɪl ðə ʃip pɛn tə hɪz lɛft; ðə flɑk mɪld əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ən ɪskeɪp. ʃæɾoʊd ʃeɪps flɪkɝɾ ɪn ðə laɪɾəd fɹʌnt wɪndoʊz ə ðə haʊs, ən ðə klæʃ ə stil ɑn stil ɹæŋ θɹu ðə dɑɹknəs. sʌɾənli wʌn ə ðə wɪndoʊz bɝst aʊtwɝɾ ɪn ə ʃaʊɝ ʌv ɡlæs ən wʊɾ əz tæm lɛp θɹu ɪt, sɔɹd stɪl ɪn hænd. hi lændəɾ ɑn ɪz fit, bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə haʊs i dæʃt təwɔɹd ðə bæk ʌv ɪt, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə mɑnstʃɹəs θɪŋz skɹæmbəlɪŋ æftɝ ɪm θɹu ðə bɹoʊkən wɪndoʊ ən ðə dɔɹweɪ.

Frightened bleats filled the sheep pen to his left; the flock milled as if trying to find an escape. Shadowed shapes flickered in the lighted front windows of the house, and the clash of steel on steel rang through the darkness. Suddenly one of the windows burst outward in a shower of glass and wood as Tam leaped through it, sword still in hand. He landed on his feet, but instead of running away from the house he dashed toward the back of it, ignoring the monstrous things scrambling after him through the broken window and the doorway.

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif. waɪ wɑz i nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ? ðən i ʌndɝstʊd. tæm hæd læs hɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs fɹəm ðə ɹɪɹ ə ðə haʊs. "fɑðɝ!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. "aɪm oʊvɝ hɪɹ!"

Rand stared in disbelief. Why was he not trying to get away? Then he understood. Tam had last heard his voice from the rear of the house. "Father!" he shouted. "I'm over here!"

ɪn mɪd-stʃɹaɪd tæm wɝld, nɑt ɹʌnɪŋ təwɔɹd ɹænd, bʌɾ əɾ ən æŋɡəl əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. "ɹʌn, læd!" hi ʃaʊɾəd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ əz ɪf tə sʌmwʌn əhɛɾ ə hɪm. "haɪd!" ə dʌzən hjudʒ fɔɹmz stʃɹimd æftɝ hɪm, hɑɹʃ ʃaʊts ən ʃɹɪl haʊlz ʃɪvɝɪŋ ði ɛɹ.

In mid-stride Tam whirled, not running toward Rand, but at an angle away from him. "Run, lad!" he shouted, gesturing with the sword as if to someone ahead of him. "Hide!" A dozen huge forms streamed after him, harsh shouts and shrill howls shivering the air.

ɹænd pʊl bæk ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊz bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɹn. ðəɹ i kəd nɑt bi sin fɹəm ðə haʊs, ɪn keɪs ɛni ʌv ðə kɹitʃɝz wɝ stɪl ɪnsaɪd. hi wɑz seɪf; fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, ət list. bʌt nɑt tæm. tæm, hu wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lid ðoʊz θɪŋz əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. hɪz hænz taɪɾənd ɑn ðə hoʊ hændəl, ən i hæd tə klɛntʃ ɪz tiθ tə stɑp ə sʌɾən læf. ə hoʊ hændəl. feɪsɪŋ wʌn ə ðoʊz kɹitʃɝz wɪð ə hoʊ hændəl wəd nɑt bi mʌtʃ laɪk pleɪɪŋ ət kɔɹɾɝstɑfs wɪð pɛɹɪn. bʌɾ i kəd nɑt lɛt tæm feɪs wʌt wɑz tʃeɪsɪŋ ɪm əloʊn.

Rand pulled back into the shadows behind the barn. There he could not be seen from the house, in case any of the creatures were still inside. He was safe; for the moment, at least. But not Tam. Tam, who was trying to lead those things away from him. His hands tightened on the hoe handle, and he had to clench his teeth to stop a sudden laugh. A hoe handle. Facing one of those creatures with a hoe handle would not be much like playing at quarterstaffs with Perrin. But he could not let Tam face what was chasing him alone.

"ɪf aɪ muv laɪk aɪ wɑz stɔkɪŋ ə ɹæbət," hi wɪspɝd tə hɪmsɛlf, "ðeɪl nɛvɝ hɪɹ mi, əɹ si mi." ði ɪɹi kɹaɪz ɛkoʊɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, ən i tʃɹaɪd tə swɑloʊ. "mɔɹ laɪk ə pæk ə stɑɹvɪŋ wʊlvz." saʊnləsli hi slɪpt əweɪ fɹəm ðə bɑɹn, təwɔɹd ðə fɔɹəst, ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə hoʊ hændəl soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ɪz hænz hɝt.

"If I move like I was stalking a rabbit," he whispered to himself, "they'll never hear me, or see me." The eerie cries echoed in the darkness, and he tried to swallow. "More like a pack of starving wolves." Soundlessly he slipped away from the barn, toward the forest, gripping the hoe handle so hard that his hands hurt.

ət fɝst, wən ðə tʃɹiz sɝaʊndəd hɪm, hi tʊk kʌmfɝt fɹəm ðɛm. ðeɪ hɛlp haɪɾ ɪm fɹəm wʌtɛvɝ ðə kɹitʃɝz wɝ ðət hæɾ ətæk ðə fɑɹm. əz i kɹɛp θɹu ðə wʊdz, ðoʊ, mun ʃædoʊz ʃɪftəd, ən ɪt bɪɡæn tə sim əz ɪf ðə dɑɹknəs ə ðə fɔɹəs tʃeɪnʒd ən muvd, tu. tʃɹiz lumd mælɛvələnli; bɹæntʃəz ɹɪθ təwɔɹd hɪm. bʌt wɝ ðeɪ dʒʌs tʃɹiz ən bɹæntʃəz? hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs hɪɹ ðə ɡɹoʊlɪŋ tʃʌkəlz staɪfəld ɪn ðɛɹ θɹoʊts waɪl ðeɪ weɪɾəd fəɹ hɪm. ðə haʊlz ə tæmz pɝsuɝz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fɪl ðə naɪt, bʌɾ ɪn ðə saɪləns ðət ɹipleɪst əm i flɪntʃt ɛvɹi taɪm ðə wɪn skɹeɪpt wʌn lɪm əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ. loʊɝ ən loʊɝ i kɹaʊtʃt, ən muv mɔɹ ən mɔɹ sloʊli. hi hɑɹdli dɛɹd tə bɹið fəɹ fɪɹ i maɪt bi hɝd.

At first, when the trees surrounded him, he took comfort from them. They helped hide him from Whatever the creatures were that had attacked the farm. As he crept through the woods, though, moon shadows shifted, and it began to seem as if the darkness of the forest changed and moved, too. Trees loomed malevolently; branches writhed toward him. But were they just trees and branches? He could almost hear the growling chuckles stifled in their throats while they waited for him. The howls of Tam's pursuers no longer filled the night, but in the silence that replaced them he flinched every time the wind scraped one limb against another. Lower and lower he crouched, and moved more and more slowly. He hardly dared to breathe for fear he might be heard.

sʌɾənli ə hæn kloʊzd oʊvɝ ɪz maʊθ fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, ən ən aɪɝn ɡɹɪp sizd ɪz ɹɪst. fɹæntəkəli hi klɔɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ wɪð ɪz fɹi hæn fəɹ səm hoʊld ɑn ði ətækɝ.

Suddenly a hand closed over his mouth from behind, and an iron grip seized his wrist. Frantically he clawed over his shoulder with his free hand for some hold on the attacker.

"doʊn bɹeɪk maɪ nɛk, læd," keɪm tæmz hɔɹs wɪspɝ.

"Don't break my neck, lad," came Tam's hoarse whisper.

ɹɪlif flʌɾəd hɪm, tɝnɪŋ ɪz mʌsəlz tə wɔɾɝ. wən ɪz fɑðɝ ɹilist ɪm i fɛl tə hɪz hænz ən niz, ɡæspɪŋ əz ɪf i hæd ɹʌn fəɹ maɪlz. tæm dʒɹɑp daʊn bɪsaɪd hɪm, linɪŋ ɑn wʌn ɛlboʊ.

Relief flooded him, turning his muscles to water. When his father released him he fell to his hands and knees, gasping as if he had run for miles. Tam dropped down beside him, leaning on one elbow.

"aɪ wʊdn əv tʃɹaɪd ðəɾ ɪf aɪ hæd θɔt haʊ mʌtʃ juv ɡɹoʊn ɪn ðə læs fju jɪɹz," tæm sɛd sɔfli. hɪz aɪz ʃɪftəd kɑnstənli əz i spoʊk, kipɪŋ ə ʃɑɹp wɑtʃ ɑn ðə dɑɹknəs. "bʌɾ aɪ hæd tə meɪk ʃʊɹ jə dɪdn spik aʊt. səm tʃɹɑləks kən hɪɹ laɪk ə dɔɡ. meɪbi bɛɾɝ."

"I wouldn't have tried that if I had thought how much you've grown in the last few years," Tam said softly. His eyes shifted constantly as he spoke, keeping a sharp watch on the darkness. "But I had to make sure you didn't speak out. Some Trollocs can hear like a dog. Maybe better."

"bʌt tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ dʒʌst. . . ." ɹænd lɛt ðə wɝdz tʃɹeɪl ɔf. nɑt dʒʌst ə stɔɹi, nɑɾ æftɝ tənaɪt. ðoʊz θɪŋz kəd bi tʃɹɑləks əɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn hɪmsɛlf fəɹ ɔl i nu. "ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ?" hi wɪspɝd. "aɪ min . . . tʃɹɑləks?"

"But Trollocs are just. . . ." Rand let the words trail off. Not just a story, not after tonight. Those things could be Trollocs or the Dark One himself for all he knew. "Are you sure?" he whispered. "I mean . . . Trollocs?"

"aɪm ʃʊɹ. ðoʊ wʌt bɹɔɾ əm tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. . . . aɪ nɛvɝ sɔ wʌn bɪfɔɹ tənaɪt, bʌɾ aɪv tɔkt wɪð mɛn u hæv, soʊ aɪ noʊ ə lɪɾəl. meɪbi ɪnʌf tə kip əs əlaɪv. lɪsən kloʊsli. eɪ tʃɹɑlɑk kən si bɛɾɝ ðən ə mæn ɪn ðə dɑɹk, bʌt bɹaɪt laɪts blaɪn ðɛm, fəɹ ə taɪm ət list. ðət meɪ bi ði oʊnli ɹizən wi ɡɑɾ əweɪ fɹəm soʊ mɛni. səm kən tʃɹæk baɪ sɛn əɹ saʊnd, bʌt ðəɹ sɛd tə bi leɪzi. ɪf wi kən kip aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ hænz lɔŋ ɪnʌf, ðeɪ ʃəd ɡɪv ʌp."

"I'm sure. Though what brought them to the Two Rivers. . . . I never saw one before tonight, but I've talked with men who have, so I know a little. Maybe enough to keep us alive. Listen closely. A Trolloc can see better than a man in the dark, but bright lights blind them, for a time at least. That may be the only reason we got away from so many. Some can track by scent or sound, but they're said to be lazy. If we can keep out of their hands long enough, they should give up."

ðət meɪd ɹænd fil oʊnli ə lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ. "ɪn ðə stɔɹiz ðeɪ heɪt mɛn, ən sɝv ðə dɑɹk wʌn."

That made Rand feel only a little better. "In the stories they hate men, and serve the Dark One."

"ɪf ɛniθɪŋ bɪlɔŋz ɪn ðə ʃɛpɝɾ ə ðə naɪts flɑks, læd, ɪts tʃɹɑləks. ðeɪ kɪl fəɹ ðə plɛʒɝ ə kɪlɪŋ, soʊ aɪv bɪn toʊld. bʌt ðæts ði ɛn ə maɪ nɑlədʒ, ɪksɛp ðət ðeɪ kænɑt bi tʃɹʌstɪɾ ənlɛs ðəɹ əfɹeɪɾ ə ju, ən ðən nɑt fɑɹ."

"If anything belongs in the Shepherd of the Night's flocks, lad, it is Trollocs. They kill for the pleasure of killing, so I've been told. But that's the end of my knowledge, except that they cannot be trusted unless they're afraid of you, and then not far."

ɹænd ʃɪvɝd. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i wəd wɑnə miɾ ɛniwʌn ə tʃɹɑlɑk wɑz əfɹeɪɾ ʌv. "du jə θɪŋk ðəɹ stɪl hʌntɪŋ fəɹ ʌs?"

Rand shivered. He did not think he would want to meet anyone a Trolloc was afraid of. "Do you think they're still hunting for us?"

"meɪbi, meɪbi nɑt. ðeɪ doʊn sim vɛɹi smɑɹt. wʌns wi ɡɑɾ ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst, aɪ sɛn ðə wʌnz æftɝ mi ɔf təwɔɹd ðə maʊntənz wɪθaʊt mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl." tæm fʌmbəld əɾ ɪz ɹaɪt saɪd, ðən pʊɾ ɪz hæn kloʊs tə hɪz feɪs. "bɛst ækt əz ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ, ðoʊ."

"Maybe, maybe not. They don't seem very smart. Once we got into the forest, I sent the ones after me off toward the mountains without much trouble." Tam fumbled at his right side, then put his hand close to his face. "Best act as if they are, though."

"jɔɹ hɝt."

"You're hurt."

"kip jəɹ vɔɪs daʊn. ɪts dʒʌst ə skɹætʃ, ən ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ tə bi dʌn əbaʊɾ ɪt naʊ, ɛniweɪ. ət lis ðə wɛðɝ simz tə bi wɔɹmɪŋ." hi leɪ bæk wɪð ə hɛvi saɪ. "pɝhæps ɪt woʊn bi tu bæd spɛndɪŋ ðə naɪɾ aʊt."

"Keep your voice down. It's just a scratch, and there is nothing to be done about it now, anyway. At least the weather seems to be warming." He lay back with a heavy sigh. "Perhaps it won't be too bad spending the night out."

ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪn ɹænd hæd dʒʌs bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ fɑn θɔts ə hɪz koʊɾ ən kloʊk. ðə tʃɹiz kʌt ðə wɝst ə ðə wɪnd, bʌt wʌt ɡʌstɪd θɹu stɪl slaɪs laɪk ə fɹoʊzən naɪf. hɛzɪɾəntli hi tʌtʃt tæmz feɪs, ən wɪnst. "jɔɹ ɑn faɪɝ. aɪ hæv tə ɡɛt jə tə nɪneɪiv."

In the back of his mind Rand had just been thinking fond thoughts of his coat and cloak. The trees cut the worst of the wind, but what gusted through still sliced like a frozen knife. Hesitantly he touched Tam's face, and winced. "You're on fire. I have to get you to Nynaeve."

"ɪn ə bɪt, læd."

"In a bit, lad."

"wi doʊn əv ɛni taɪm tə weɪst. ɪts ə lɔŋ weɪ ɪn ðə dɑɹk." hi skɹæmbəl tə hɪz fiɾ ən tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl ɪz fɑðɝ ʌp. ə ɡɹoʊn bɛɹli staɪfəl baɪ tæmz klɛntʃt tiθ meɪd ɹænd heɪstəli iz ɪm bæk daʊn.

"We don't have any time to waste. It's a long way in the dark." He scrambled to his feet and tried to pull his father up. A groan barely stifled by Tam's clenched teeth made Rand hastily ease him back down.

"lɛt mi ɹɛst ə waɪl, bɔɪ. aɪm taɪɝd."

"Let me rest a while, boy. I'm tired."

ɹænd paʊndɪɾ ɪz fɪst ɑn ɪz θaɪ. snʌɡ ɪn ðə fɑɹmhaʊs, wɪð ə faɪɝ ən blæŋkəts, plɛnti ʌv wɔɾɝ ən wɪloʊbɑɹk, hi maɪɾ əv bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə weɪt fəɹ deɪbɹeɪk bɪfɔɹ hɪtʃɪŋ bɛlə ən teɪkɪŋ tæm ɪndə ðə vɪlədʒ. hɪɹ wɑz noʊ faɪɝ, noʊ blæŋkəts, noʊ kɑɹt, ən noʊ bɛlə. bʌt ðoʊz θɪŋz wɝ stɪl bæk ət ðə haʊs. ɪf i kəd nɑt kæɹi tæm tə ðɛm, pɝhæps i kəd bɹɪŋ səm ə ðɛm, ət list, tə tæm. ɪf ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ ɡɔn. ðeɪ hæd tə ɡoʊ sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ.

Rand pounded his fist on his thigh. Snug in the farmhouse, with a fire and blankets, plenty of water and willowbark, he might have been willing to wait for daybreak before hitching Bela and taking Tam into the village. Here was no fire, no blankets, no cart, and no Bela. But those things were still back at the house. If he could not carry Tam to them, perhaps he could bring some of them, at least, to Tam. If the Trollocs were gone. They had to go sooner or later.

hi lʊkt ət ðə hoʊ hændəl, ðən dʒɹɑpt ɪt. ɪnstɛɾ i dʒɹu tæmz sɔɹd. ðə bleɪd ɡlim dʌli ɪn ðə peɪl munlaɪt. ðə lɔŋ hɪl fɛlt ɑɾ ɪn ɪz hænd; ðə weɪɾ ən hɛft wɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ. hi slæʃt ət ði ɛɹ ə fju taɪmz bɪfɔɹ stɑpɪŋ wɪð ə saɪ. slæʃɪŋ əɾ ɛɹ wɑz izi. ɪf i hæd tə də ɪɾ əɡɛnst ə tʃɹɑlɑk i wɑz ʃʊɹli dʒʌst əz laɪkli tə ɹʌn ɪnstɛd, əɹ fɹiz stɪf soʊ hi kəd nɑt muv əɾ ɔl əntɪl ðə tʃɹɑlɑk swʌŋ wʌn ə ðoʊz ɑd sɔɹdz ænd. . . . stɑp ɪt! ɪts nɑt hɛlpɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ!

He looked at the hoe handle, then dropped it. Instead he drew Tam's sword. The blade gleamed dully in the pale moonlight. The long hilt felt odd in his hand; the weight and heft were strange. He slashed at the air a few times before stopping with a sigh. Slashing at air was easy. If he had to do it against a Trolloc he was surely just as likely to run instead, or freeze stiff so he could not move at all until the Trolloc swung one of those odd swords and. . . . Stop it! It's not helping anything!

əz i stɑɹɾəd tə ɹaɪz, tæm kɑɾ ɪz ɑɹm. "wɛɹ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ?"

As he started to rise, Tam caught his arm. "Where are you going?"

"wi nid ðə kɑɹt," hi sɛd dʒɛnli. "æn blæŋkəts." hi wɑz ʃɑkt ət haʊ izəli hi pʊld ɪz fɑðɝz hæn fɹəm ɪz sliv. "ɹɛst, ən əl bi bæk."

"We need the cart," he said gently. "And blankets." He was shocked at how easily he pulled his father's hand from his sleeve. "Rest, and I'll be back."

"kɛɹfəl," tæm bɹiðd.

"Careful," Tam breathed.

hi kəd nɑt si tæmz feɪs ɪn ðə munlaɪt, bʌɾ i kəd fil ɪz aɪz ɑn hɪm. "aɪ wɪl bi." əz kɛɹfəl əz ə maʊs ɪksplɔɹɪŋ ə hɔks nɛst, hi θɔt.

He could not see Tam's face in the moonlight, but he could feel his eyes on him. "I will be." As careful as a mouse exploring a hawk's nest, he thought.

əz saɪlənli əz ənʌðɝ ʃædoʊ, hi slɪɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. hi θɔɾ ʌv ɔl ðə taɪmz i hæd pleɪd tæɡ ɪn ðə wʊdz wɪð ɪz fɹɛnz əz tʃɪlʒɹən, stɔkɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ, stʃɹeɪnɪŋ nɑt tə bi hɝɾ əntɪl i pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn sʌmwʌnz ʃoʊldɝ. sʌmhaʊ hi kəd nɑt meɪk ðɪs sim ðə seɪm.

As silently as another shadow, he slid into the darkness. He thought of all the times he had played tag in the woods with his friends as children, stalking one another, straining not to be heard until he put a hand on someone's shoulder. Somehow he could not make this seem the same.

kɹipɪŋ fɹəm tʃɹi tə tʃɹi, hi tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ə plæn, bʌt baɪ ðə taɪm i ɹitʃt ði ɛdʒ ə ðə wʊdz i hæd meɪɾ ən dɪskɑɹɾɪd tɛn. ɛvɹiθɪŋ dɪpɛndəɾ ɑn wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ stɪl ðɛɹ. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn, hi kəd sɪmpli wɔk ʌp tə ðə haʊs ən teɪk wʌɾ i niɾəd. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ stɪl ðɛɹ. . . . ɪn ðət keɪs, ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪt bʌt ɡoʊ bæk tə tæm. hi dɪd nɑt laɪk ɪt, bʌɾ i kəd də tæm noʊ ɡʊd baɪ ɡɛɾɪŋ kɪld.

Creeping from tree to tree, he tried to make a plan, but by the time he reached the edge of the woods he had made and discarded ten. Everything depended on whether or not the Trollocs were still there. If they were gone, he could simply walk up to the house and take what he needed. If they were still there. . . . In that case, there was nothing for it but go back to Tam. He did not like it, but he could do Tam no good by getting killed.

hi pɪɹd təwɔɹd ðə fɑɹm bɪldɪŋz. ðə bɑɹn ən ðə ʃip pɛn wɝ oʊnli dɑɹk ʃeɪps ɪn ðə munlaɪt. laɪt spɪl fɹəm ðə fɹʌnt wɪndoʊz ə ðə haʊs, ðoʊ, ən θɹu ði oʊpən fɹʌn dɔɹ. dʒʌs ðə kændəlz fɑðɝ lɪt, əɹ ɑɹ ðəɹ tʃɹɑləks weɪɾɪŋ?

He peered toward the farm buildings. The barn and the sheep pen were only dark shapes in the moonlight. Light spilled from the front windows of the house, though, and through the open front door. Just the candles father lit, or are there Trollocs waiting?

hi dʒʌmp kənvʌlsɪvli əɾ ə naɪthɔks ɹiɾi kɹaɪ, ðən sæɡd əɡɛnst ə tʃɹi, ʃeɪkɪŋ. ðɪs wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪm noʊwɛɹ. dʒɹɑpɪŋ tə hɪz bɛli, hi bɪɡæn tə kɹɔl, hoʊldɪŋ ðə sɔɹɾ ɔkwɝdli bɪfɔɹ hɪm. hi kɛpt ɪz tʃɪn ɪn ðə dɝɾ ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə bæk ə ðə ʃip pɛn.

He jumped convulsively at a nighthawk's reedy cry, then sagged against a tree, shaking. This was getting him nowhere. Dropping to his belly, he began to crawl, holding the sword awkwardly before him. He kept his chin in the dirt all the way to the back of the sheep pen.

kɹaʊtʃt əɡɛns ðə stoʊn wɔl, hi lɪsənd. nɑɾ ə saʊn dɪstɝb ðə naɪt. kɛɹfəli hi izd ʌp ɪnʌf tə lʊk oʊvɝ ðə wɔl. nʌθɪŋ muvd ɪn ðə fɑɹmjɑɹd. noʊ ʃædoʊz flɪkɝɾ əɡɛns ðə lɪt wɪndoʊz ə ðə haʊs, əɹ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ. bɛlə ən ðə kɑɹt fɝst, əɹ ðə blæŋkəts ən ʌðɝ θɪŋz. ɪt wɑz ðə laɪt ðət dɪsaɪɾɪd hɪm. ðə bɑɹn wɑz dɑɹk. ɛniθɪŋ kəd bi weɪɾɪŋ ɪnsaɪd, ən i wəɾ əv noʊ weɪ ʌv noʊɪŋ əntɪl ɪt wɑz tu leɪt. ət list i wəd bi eɪbəl tə si wʌt wɑz ɪnsaɪd ðə haʊs.

Crouched against the stone wall, he listened. Not a sound disturbed the night. Carefully he eased up enough to look over the wall. Nothing moved in the farmyard. No shadows flickered against the lit windows of the house, or in the doorway. Bela and the cart first, or the blankets and other things. It was the light that decided him. The barn was dark. Anything could be waiting inside, and he would have no way of knowing until it was too late. At least he would be able to see what was inside the house.

əz i stɑɹɾəd tə loʊɝ hɪmsɛlf əɡɛn, hi stɑp sʌɾənli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saʊnd. moʊst ə ðə ʃip maɪɾ əv sɛɾəld daʊn ɔlɹɛɾi ən ɡɔn bæk tə slip, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz nɑt laɪkli, bʌɾ ə fju wɝ ɔlweɪz əweɪk ivən ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə naɪt, ɹʌslɪŋ əbaʊt, bliɾɪŋ naʊ ən əɡɛn. hi kəd bɛɹli meɪk aʊt ðə ʃæɾoʊi maʊnz ə ʃip ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. wʌn leɪ ɔlmoʊs bɪniθ hɪm.

As he started to lower himself again, he stopped suddenly. There was no sound. Most of the sheep might have settled down already and gone back to sleep, though it was not likely, but a few were always awake even in the middle of the night, rustling about, bleating now and again. He could barely make out the shadowy mounds of sheep on the ground. One lay almost beneath him.

tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk noʊ nɔɪz, hi hɔɪstəd hɪmsɛlf ɑntu ðə wɔl əntɪl i kəd stʃɹɛtʃ aʊɾ ə hæn tə ðə dɪm ʃeɪp. hɪz fɪŋɡɝz tʌtʃt kɝli wʊl, ðən wɛtnəs; ðə ʃip dɪd nɑt muv. bɹɛθ lɛft ɪm ɪn ə ɹʌʃ əz i pʊʃt bæk, ɔlmoʊs dʒɹɑpɪŋ ðə sɔɹɾ əz i fɛl tə ðə ɡɹaʊn aʊtsaɪd ðə pɛn. ðeɪ kɪl fəɹ fʌn. ʃɑkəli hi skɹʌb ðə wɛtnəs fɹəm ɪz hæn ɪn ðə dɝt.

Trying to make no noise, he hoisted himself onto the wall until he could stretch out a hand to the dim shape. His fingers touched curly wool, then wetness; the sheep did not move. Breath left him in a rush as he pushed back, almost dropping the sword as he fell to the ground outside the pen. They kill for fun. Shakily he scrubbed the wetness from his hand in the dirt.

fɪɹsli hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf ðət nʌθɪŋ hæd tʃeɪnʒd. ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd dʌn ðɛɹ bʊtʃɝi ən ɡɔn. ɹɪpiɾɪŋ ðəɾ ɪn ɪz maɪnd, hi kɹɔld ɑn əkɹɔs ðə fɑɹmjɑɹd, kipɪŋ əz loʊ əz i kʊd, bʌt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə wɑtʃ ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, tu. hi hæd nɛvɝ θɔɾ i wəɾ ɛnvi ən ɝθwɝm.

Fiercely he told himself that nothing had changed. The Trollocs had done their butchery and gone. Repeating that in his mind, he crawled on across the farmyard, keeping as low as he could, but trying to watch every direction, too. He had never thought he would envy an earthworm.

ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə haʊs i leɪ kloʊs bɪsaɪd ðə wɔl, bɪniθ ðə bɹoʊkən wɪndoʊ, ən lɪsənd. ðə dʌl θəɾɪŋ ə blʌɾ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz wɑz ðə laʊɾəst saʊn i hɝd. sloʊli hi ɹɪɹɾ ʌp ən pɪɹɾ ɪnsaɪd.

At the front of the house he lay close beside the wall, beneath the broken window, and listened. The dull thudding of blood in his ears was the loudest sound he heard. Slowly he reared up and peered inside.

ðə stupɑt leɪ ʌpsaɪd daʊn ɪn ði æʃəz ɑn ðə hɑɹθ. splɪntɝd, bɹoʊkən wʊd lɪɾɝd ðə ɹum; nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl pis ə fɝnɪtʃɝ ɹɪmeɪn hoʊl. ivən ðə teɪbəl ɹɛstəɾ əɾ ən æŋɡəl, tu lɛɡz hæk tə ɹʌf stʌbz. ɛvɹi dʒɹɔɹ hæd bɪn pʊld aʊɾ ən smæʃt; ɛvɹi kʌbɝɾ ən kæbənət stʊɾ oʊpən, mɛni dɔɹz hæŋɪŋ baɪ wʌn hɪnʒ. ðɛɹ kɑntɛns wɝ stʃɹun oʊvɝ ðə ɹɛkədʒ, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz dʌstɪd wɪð waɪt. flaʊɝ ən sɔlt, tə dʒʌdʒ fɹəm ðə slæʃt sæks tɔs daʊn baɪ ðə faɪɝpleɪs. fɔɹ twɪstəd bɑɾiz meɪɾ ə tæŋɡəl ɪn ðə ɹɛmnəns ə ðə fɝnɪʃɪŋz. tʃɹɑləks.

The stewpot lay upside down in the ashes on the hearth. Splintered, broken wood littered the room; not a single piece of furniture remained whole. Even the table rested at an angle, two legs hacked to rough stubs. Every drawer had been pulled out and smashed; every cupboard and cabinet stood open, many doors hanging by one hinge. Their contents were strewn over the wreckage, and everything was dusted with white. Flour and salt, to judge from the slashed sacks tossed down by the fireplace. Four twisted bodies made a tangle in the remnants of the furnishings. Trollocs.

ɹænd ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd wʌn baɪ ɪts ɹæmz hɔɹnz. ði ʌðɝz wɝ mʌtʃ ðə seɪm, ivən ɪn ðɛɹ dɪfɝənsɪz, ə ɹipʌlsɪv mɛlæŋ ə hjumən feɪsəz dɪstɔɹɾəd baɪ mʌzəlz, hɔɹnz, fɛðɝz, ən fɝ. ðɛɹ hænz, ɔlmoʊs hjumən, oʊnli meɪɾ ɪt wɝs. tu wɔɹ buts; ði ʌðɝz hæd hʊvz. hi wɑtʃt wɪθaʊt blɪŋkɪŋ əntɪl ɪz aɪz bɝnd. nʌn ə ðə tʃɹɑləks muvd. ðeɪ hæd tə bi dɛd. ən tæm wɑz weɪɾɪŋ.

Rand recognized one by its ram's horns. The others were much the same, even in their differences, a repulsive melange of human faces distorted by muzzles, horns, feathers, and fur. Their hands, almost human, only made it worse. Two wore boots; the others had hooves. He watched without blinking until his eyes burned. None of the Trollocs moved. They had to be dead. And Tam was waiting.
