hi ɹæn ɪn θɹu ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ ən stɑpt, ɡæɡɪŋ ət ðə stɛntʃ. ə steɪbəl ðət hæd nɑt bɪn mʌkt aʊɾ ɪn mʌnθs wɑz ði oʊnli θɪŋ i kəd θɪŋk ə ðət maɪt kʌm kloʊs tə mætʃɪŋ ɪt. vaɪl smɪɹz dɪfaɪl ðə wɔlz. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɹið θɹu hɪz maʊθ, hi hɝidli bɪɡæn poʊkɪŋ θɹu ðə mɛs ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə wɔɾɝbæɡ ɪn wʌn ə ðə kʌbɝdz.

He ran in through the front door and stopped, gagging at the stench. A stable that had not been mucked out in months was the only thing he could think of that might come close to matching it. Vile smears defiled the walls. Trying to breathe through his mouth, he hurriedly began poking through the mess on the floor. There had been a waterbag in one of the cupboards.

ə skɹeɪpɪŋ saʊn bɪhaɪn ɪm sɛn ə tʃɪl tə hɪz mɛɹoʊ, ən i spʌn, ɔlmoʊs fɔlɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ə ðə teɪbəl. hi kɑt hɪmsɛlf, ən moʊn bɪhaɪn tiθ ðət wʊɾə tʃæɾɝd hæɾ i nɑt hæɾ əm klɛntʃt əntɪl ɪz dʒɔ ætʃt.

A scraping sound behind him sent a chill to his marrow, and he spun, almost falling over the remains of the table. He caught himself, and moaned behind teeth that would have chattered had he not had them clenched until his jaw ached.

wʌn ə ðə tʃɹɑləks wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ tə ɪts fit. ə wʊlfs mʌzəl dʒʌɾɪd aʊt bɪloʊ sʌŋkən aɪz. flæt, ɪmoʊʃənləs aɪz, ən ɔl tu hjumən. hɛɹi, pɔɪntəɾ ɪɹz twɪtʃt ɪnsɛsənli. ɪt stɛpt oʊvɝ wʌn ʌv ɪts dɛd kəmpænjənz ɑn ʃɑɹp ɡoʊt hʊvz. ðə seɪm blæk meɪl ði ʌðɝz wɔɹ ɹæspt əɡɛns lɛðɝ tʃɹaʊzɝz, ən wʌn ə ðə hjudʒ, saɪð-kɝv sɔɹdz swʌŋ əɾ ɪts saɪd.

One of the Trollocs was getting to its feet. A wolf's muzzle jutted out below sunken eyes. Flat, emotionless eyes, and all too human. Hairy, pointed ears twitched incessantly. It stepped over one of its dead companions on sharp goat hooves. The same black mail the others wore rasped against leather trousers, and one of the huge, scythe-curved swords swung at its side.

ɪt mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ, ɡʌɾɝəl ən ʃɑɹp, ðən sɛd, "ʌðɝz ɡoʊ əweɪ. nɑɹɡ steɪ. nɑɹɡ smɑɹt." ðə wɝdz wɝ dɪstɔɹɾəd ən hɑɹd tə ʌndɝstænd, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ə maʊθ nɛvɝ mɛn fəɹ hjumən spitʃ. ɪts toʊn wɑz mɛn tə bi suðɪŋ, hi θɔt, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt teɪk ɪz aɪz ɔf ðə steɪn tiθ, lɔŋ ən ʃɑɹp, ðət flæʃt ɛvɹi taɪm ðə kɹitʃɝ spoʊk. "nɑɹɡ noʊ səm kʌm bæk sʌmtaɪm. nɑɹɡ weɪt. jə noʊ nid sɔɹd. pʊt sɔɹd daʊn."

It muttered something, guttural and sharp, then said, "Others go away. Narg stay. Narg smart." The words were distorted and hard to understand, coming from a mouth never meant for human speech. Its tone was meant to be soothing, he thought, but he could not take his eyes off the stained teeth, long and sharp, that flashed every time the creature spoke. "Narg know some come back sometime. Narg wait. You no need sword. Put sword down."

əntɪl ðə tʃɹɑlɑk spoʊk ɹænd hæd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i hɛl tæmz sɔɹd weɪvɝɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ɪm ɪn boʊθ hænz, ɪts pɔɪn eɪmd ət ðə hjudʒ kɹitʃɝ. ɪt taʊɝd hɛɾ ən ʃoʊldɝz əbʌv hɪm, wɪð ə tʃɛst ən ɑɹmz tə dwɔɹf mæstɝ luhən.

Until the Trolloc spoke Rand had not realized that he held Tam's sword wavering before him in both hands, its point aimed at the huge creature. It towered head and shoulders above him, with a chest and arms to dwarf Master Luhhan.

"nɑɹɡ noʊ hɝt." ɪt tʊk ə stɛp kloʊsɝ, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ. "ju pʊt sɔɹd daʊn." ðə dɑɹk hɛɹ ɑn ðə bæks ʌv ɪts hænz wɑz θɪk, laɪk fɝ.

"Narg no hurt." It took a step closer, gesturing. "You put sword down." The dark hair on the backs of its hands was thick, like fur.

"steɪ bæk," ɹænd sɛd, wɪʃɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs wɝ stɛɾiɝ. "waɪ dɪd jə də ðɪs? waɪ?"

"Stay back," Rand said, wishing his voice were steadier. "Why did you do this? Why?"

"lʒə deɪɛɡ ɹɑɡdə!" ðə snɑɹl kwɪkli bɪkeɪm ə tuθi smaɪl. "pʊt sɔɹd daʊn. nɑɹɡ noʊ hɝt. mɹdʒɹɑl wɑn tɔk ju." ə flæʃ ʌv ɪmoʊʃən kɹɔs ðə dɪstɔɹɾəd feɪs. fɪɹ. "ʌðɝz kʌm bæk, jə tɔk mɹdʒɹɑl." ɪt tʊk ənʌðɝ stɛp, wʌn bɪɡ hæn kʌmɪŋ tə ɹɛst ɑn ɪts oʊn sɔɹd hɪlt. "ju pʊt sɔɹd daʊn."

"Vlja daeg roghda!" The snarl quickly became a toothy smile. "Put sword down. Narg no hurt. Myrddraal want talk you." A flash of emotion crossed the distorted face. Fear. "Others come back, you talk Myrddraal." It took another step, one big hand coming to rest on its own sword hilt. "You put sword down."

ɹænd wɛɾ ɪz lɪps. mɹdʒɹɑl! ðə wɝst ə ðə stɔɹiz wɑz wɔkɪŋ tənaɪt. ɪf ə feɪd wɑz kʌmɪŋ, ɪt meɪɾ ə tʃɹɑlɑk peɪl baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən. hi hæd tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ. bʌɾ ɪf ðə tʃɹɑlɑk dʒɹu ðət mæsɪv bleɪɾ i wəd nɑɾ əv ə tʃæns. hi fɔɹst ɪz lɪps ɪndə ə ʃeɪki smaɪl. "ɔl ɹaɪt." ɡɹɪp taɪɾənɪŋ ɑn ðə sɔɹd, hi lɛt boʊθ hænz dʒɹɑp tə hɪz saɪdz. "aɪl tɔk."

Rand wet his lips. Myrddraal! The worst of the stories was walking tonight. If a Fade was coming, it made a Trolloc pale by comparison. He had to get away. But if the Trolloc drew that massive blade he would not have a chance. He forced his lips into a shaky smile. "All right." Grip tightening on the sword, he let both hands drop to his sides. "I'll talk."

ðə wʊlf-smaɪl bɪkeɪm ə snɑɹl, ən ðə tʃɹɑlɑk lʌnʒd fəɹ hɪm. ɹænd hæd nɑt θɔɾ ɛniθɪŋ ðət bɪɡ kəd muv soʊ fæst. dɛspɝətli hi bɹɔɾ ɪz sɔɹɾ ʌp. ðə mɑnstʃɹəs bɑɾi kɹæʃt ɪndə hɪm, slæmɪŋ ɪm əɡɛns ðə wɔl. bɹɛθ lɛft ɪz lʌŋz ɪn wʌn ɡæsp. hi fɔt fəɹ ɛɹ əz ðeɪ fɛl tə ðə flɔɹ təɡɛðɝ, ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ɑn tɑp. fɹæntəkəli hi stʃɹʌɡəl bɪniθ ðə kɹʌʃɪŋ weɪt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə əvɔɪd θɪk hænz ɡɹoʊpɪŋ fəɹ hɪm, ən snæpɪŋ dʒɔz.

The wolf-smile became a snarl, and the Trolloc lunged for him. Rand had not thought anything that big could move so fast. Desperately he brought his sword up. The monstrous body crashed into him, slamming him against the wall. Breath left his lungs in one gasp. He fought for air as they fell to the floor together, the Trolloc on top. Frantically he struggled beneath the crushing weight, trying to avoid thick hands groping for him, and snapping jaws.

əbɹʌpli ðə tʃɹɑlɑk spæzmd ən wɑz stɪl. bæɾɝd ən bɹuzd, hæf sʌfəkeɪɾɪd baɪ ðə bʌlk ɑn tɑp ə hɪm, fəɹ ə moʊmən ɹænd kəɾ oʊnli laɪ ðəɹ ɪn dɪsbɪlif. kwɪkli hi keɪm tə hɪz sɛnsɪz, ðoʊ, ɪnʌf tə ɹɪð aʊt fɹəm ʌndɝ ðə bɑɾi, ət list. ən bɑɾi ɪt wɑz. ðə blʌɾid bleɪɾ ə tæmz sɔɹd stʊɾ aʊt fɹəm ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑks bæk. hi hæd ɡɑɾən ɪɾ ʌp ɪn taɪm æftɝ ɔl. blʌd kʌvɝd ɹændz hænz, əz wɛl, ən meɪɾ ə blækɪʃ smɪɹ əkɹɔs ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz ʃɝt. hɪz stʌmək tʃɝnd, ən i swɑloʊd hɑɹd tə kip fɹəm biɪŋ sɪk. hi ʃʊk əz hɑɹɾ əz i hæɾ ɪn ðə wɝst ə hɪz fɪɹ, bʌt ðɪs taɪm ɪn ɹɪlif ət stɪl biɪŋ əlaɪv.

Abruptly the Trolloc spasmed and was still. Battered and bruised, half suffocated by the bulk on top of him, for a moment Rand could only lie there in disbelief. Quickly he came to his senses, though, enough to writhe out from under the body, at least. And body it was. The bloodied blade of Tam's sword stood out from the center of the Trolloc's back. He had gotten it up in time after all. Blood covered Rand's hands, as well, and made a blackish smear across the front of his shirt. His stomach churned, and he swallowed hard to keep from being sick. He shook as hard as he had in the worst of his fear, but this time in relief at still being alive.

ʌðɝz kʌm bæk, ðə tʃɹɑlɑk hæd sɛd. ði ʌðɝ tʃɹɑləks wəd bi ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə fɑɹmhaʊs. ən ə mɹdʒɹɑl, ə feɪd. ðə stɔɹiz sɛd feɪdz wɝ twɛnti fit tɔl, wɪð aɪz ə faɪɝ, ən ðeɪ ɹoʊd ʃædoʊz laɪk hɔɹsəz. wən ə feɪd tɝn saɪdweɪz, ɪt dɪsəpɪɹd, ən noʊ wɔl kəd stɑp ðɛm. hi hæd tə də wʌɾ i hæd kʌm fɔɹ, ən ɡɛɾ əweɪ kwɪkli.

Others come back, the Trolloc had said. The other Trollocs would be returning to the farmhouse. And a Myrddraal, a Fade. The stories said Fades were twenty feet tall, with eyes of fire, and they rode shadows like horses. When a Fade turned sideways, it disappeared, and no wall could stop them. He had to do what he had come for, and get away quickly.

ɡɹʌntɪŋ wɪð ði ɛfɝɾ i hiv ðə tʃɹɑlɑks bɑɾi oʊvɝ tə ɡɛt tə ðə sɔɹd - ən ɔlmoʊst ɹæn wən oʊpən aɪz stɛɹɾ ət hɪm. ɪt tʊk ɪm ə mɪnət tə ɹilaɪz ðeɪ wɝ stɛɹɪŋ θɹu ðə ɡleɪz ə dɛθ.

Grunting with the effort he heaved the Trolloc's body over to get to the sword - and almost ran when open eyes stared at him. It took him a minute to realize they were staring through the glaze of death.

hi waɪpt ɪz hænz ɑn ə tæɾɝd ɹæɡ - ɪt hæd bɪn wʌn ə tæmz ʃɝts oʊnli ðət mɔɹnɪŋ - ən tʌɡd ðə bleɪd fɹi. klinɪŋ ðə sɔɹd, hi ɹɪlʌktənli dʒɹɑp ðə ɹæɡ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ nitnəs, hi θɔt wɪð ə læf ðəɾ i hæd tə klæmp ɪz tiθ ʃʌt tə stɑp. hi dɪd nɑt si haʊ ðeɪ kəɾ ɛvɝ klin ðə haʊs wɛl ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪt tə bi lɪvd ɪn əɡɛn. ðə hɔɹəbəl stɛntʃ hæd pɹɑbli ɔlɹɛɾi soʊkt ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ðə tɪmbɝz. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm tə θɪŋk ə ðæt. noʊ taɪm fəɹ nitnəs. noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ, meɪbi.

He wiped his hands on a tattered rag - it had been one of Tam's shirts only that morning - and tugged the blade free. Cleaning the sword, he reluctantly dropped the rag on the floor. There was no time for neatness, he thought with a laugh that he had to clamp his teeth shut to stop. He did not see how they could ever clean the house well enough for it to be lived in again. The horrible stench had probably already soaked right into the timbers. But there was no time to think of that. No time for neatness. No time for anything, maybe.

hi wɑz ʃʊɹ i wɑz fɝɡɛɾɪŋ ɛni nʌmbɝ ə θɪŋz ðeɪ wəd nid, bʌt tæm wɑz weɪɾɪŋ, ən ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ kʌmɪŋ bæk. hi ɡæðɝd wʌɾ i kəd θɪŋk ʌv ɑn ðə ɹʌn. blæŋkəts fɹəm ðə bɛdʒɹumz əpstɛɹz, ən klin klɔθs tə bændɪdʒ tæmz waʊnd. ðɛɹ kloʊks ən koʊts. ə wɔɾɝbæɡ ðəɾ i kæɹid wən i tʊk ðə ʃip tə pæstʃɝ. ə klin ʃɝt. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wən i wəɾ əv taɪm tə tʃeɪnʒ, bʌɾ i wɑntəd tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz blʌd-smɪɹd ʃɝɾ ət ðə fɝst ɑpɝtunəɾi. ðə smɔl bæɡz ʌv wɪloʊbɑɹk ən ðɛɹ ʌðɝ mɛɾəsənz wɝ pɑɹɾ ʌv ə dɑɹk, mʌɾi-lʊkɪŋ paɪl i kəd nɑt bɹɪŋ hɪmsɛlf tə tʌtʃ.

He was sure he was forgetting any number of things they would need, but Tam was waiting, and the Trollocs were coming back. He gathered what he could think of on the run. Blankets from the bedrooms upstairs, and clean cloths to bandage Tam's wound. Their cloaks and coats. A waterbag that he carried when he took the sheep to pasture. A clean shirt. He did not know when he would have time to change, but he wanted to get out of his blood-smeared shirt at the first opportunity. The small bags of willowbark and their other medicines were part of a dark, muddy-looking pile he could not bring himself to touch.

wʌn bʌkəɾ ə ðə wɔɾɝ tæm hæd bɹɔɾ ɪn stɪl stʊd baɪ ðə faɪɝpleɪs, mɝækjələsli ənspɪld ən əntʌtʃt. hi fɪl ðə wɔɾɝbæɡ fɹəm ɪt, ɡeɪv ɪz hænz ə heɪsti wɑʃ ɪn ðə ɹɛst, ən meɪd wʌn mɔɹ kwɪk sɝtʃ fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ i maɪɾ əv fɝɡɑɾən. hi faʊn ɪz baʊ əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛkədʒ, bɹoʊkən klinli ɪn tu ət ðə θɪkəs pɔɪnt. hi ʃʌɾɝəd əz i lɛt ðə pisəz fɔl. wʌɾ i hæd ɡæðɝɾ ɔlɹɛɾi wəɾ əv tə du, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd. kwɪkli hi paɪld ɛvɹiθɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə dɔɹ.

One bucket of the water Tam had brought in still stood by the fireplace, miraculously unspilled and untouched. He filled the waterbag from it, gave his hands a hasty wash in the rest, and made one more quick search for anything he might have forgotten. He found his bow among the wreckage, broken cleanly in two at the thickest point. He shuddered as he let the pieces fall. What he had gathered already would have to do, he decided. Quickly he piled everything outside the door.

ðə læs θɪŋ bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ ðə haʊs, hi dʌɡ ə ʃʌɾɝd læntɝn fɹəm ðə mɛs ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ɪt stɪl hɛld ɔɪl. laɪɾɪŋ ɪt fɹəm wʌn ə ðə kændəlz, hi kloʊz ðə ʃʌɾɝz - pɑɹtli əɡɛns ðə wɪnd, bʌt moʊsli tə kip fɹəm dʒɹɔɪŋ ətɛnʃən - ən hɝiɾ aʊtsaɪd wɪð ðə læntɝn ɪn wʌn hæn ən ðə sɔɹɾ ɪn ði ʌðɝ. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌɾ i wəd faɪn ɪn ðə bɑɹn. ðə ʃip pɛn kɛpt ɪm fɹəm hoʊpɪŋ tu mʌtʃ. bʌɾ i niɾəd ðə kɑɹt tə ɡɛt tæm tə ɛmənz fild, ən fəɹ ðə kɑɹɾ i niɾəd bɛlə. nəsɛsəɾi meɪɾ ɪm hoʊp ə lɪɾəl.

The last thing before leaving the house, he dug a shuttered lantern from the mess on the floor. It still held oil. Lighting it from one of the candles, he closed the shutters - partly against the wind, but mostly to keep from drawing attention - and hurried outside with the lantern in one hand and the sword in the other. He was not sure what he would find in the barn. The sheep pen kept him from hoping too much. But he needed the cart to get Tam to Emond's Field, and for the cart he needed Bela. Necessity made him hope a little.

ðə bɑɹn dɔɹz stʊɾ oʊpən, wʌn kɹikɪŋ ɑn ɪts hɪnʒɪz əz ɪt ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ðə wɪnd. ði ɪntɪɹiɝ lʊkt əz ɪɾ ɔlweɪz hæd, ət fɝst. ðən ɪz aɪz fɛl ɑn ɛmpti stɔlz, ðə stɔl dɔɹz ɹɪp fɹəm ðɛɹ hɪnʒɪz. bɛlə ən ðə kaʊ wɝ ɡɔn. kwɪkli hi wɛn tə ðə bæk ə ðə bɑɹn. ðə kɑɹt leɪ ɑn ɪts saɪd, hæf ðə spoʊks bɹoʊkən aʊɾ ʌv ɪts wilz. wʌn ʃæft wɑz oʊnli ə fʊt-lɔŋ stʌmp.

The barn doors stood open, one creaking on its hinges as it shifted in the wind. The interior looked as it always had, at first. Then his eyes fell on empty stalls, the stall doors ripped from their hinges. Bela and the cow were gone. Quickly he went to the back of the barn. The cart lay on its side, half the spokes broken out of its wheels. One shaft was only a foot-long stump.

ðə dɪspɛɹ i hæd bɪn hoʊldɪŋ ət beɪ fɪl hɪm. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i kəd kæɹi tæm əz fɑɹ əz ðə vɪlədʒ ivən ɪf ɪz fɑðɝ kəd bɛɹ tə bi kæɹid. ðə peɪn ʌv ɪt maɪt kɪl tæm mɔɹ kwɪkli ðən ðə fivɝ. stɪl, ɪt wɑz ði oʊnli tʃæns lɛft. hi hæd dʌn ɔl i kəd də hɪɹ. əz i tɝn tə ɡoʊ, hɪz aɪz fɛl ɑn ðə hækt-ɔf kɑɹt ʃæf laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə stʃɹɔ-stʃɹun flɔɹ. sʌɾənli hi smaɪld.

The despair he had been holding at bay filled him. He was not sure he could carry Tam as far as the village even if his father could bear to be carried. The pain of it might kill Tam more quickly than the fever. Still, it was the only chance left. He had done all he could do here. As he turned to go, his eyes fell on the hacked-off cart shaft lying on the straw-strewn floor. Suddenly he smiled.

hɝidli hi sɛt ðə læntɝn ən ðə sɔɹɾ ɑn ðə stʃɹɔ-kʌvɝd flɔɹ, ən ɪn ðə nɛkst ɪnstən i wɑz ɹɛslɪŋ wɪð ðə kɑɹt, tɪpɪŋ ɪt bæk oʊvɝ tə fɔl əpɹaɪt wɪð ə snæp ə mɔɹ bɹeɪkɪŋ spoʊks, ðən θɹoʊɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ɪndə ɪt tə hiv ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. ði ʌndæmədʒd ʃæf stʊd stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt. snætʃɪŋ ʌp ðə sɔɹɾ i hækt ət ðə wɛl-sizən æʃ. tə hɪz pliz sɝpɹaɪz ɡɹeɪt tʃɪps flu wɪð ɪz stʃɹoʊks, ən i kʌt θɹu əz kwɪkli əz i kəɾ əv wɪð ə ɡʊɾ æks.

Hurriedly he set the lantern and the sword on the straw-covered floor, and in the next instant he was wrestling with the cart, tipping it back over to fall upright with a snap of more breaking spokes, then throwing his shoulder into it to heave it over on the other side. The undamaged shaft stood straight out. Snatching up the sword he hacked at the well-seasoned ash. To his pleased surprise great chips flew with his strokes, and he cut through as quickly as he could have with a good axe.

wən ðə ʃæft fɛl fɹi, hi lʊkt ət ðə sɔɹd bleɪɾ ɪn wʌndɝ. ivən ðə bɛst-ʃɑɹpən æks wʊɾə dʌl tʃɑpɪŋ θɹu ðət hɑɹd, eɪdʒd wʊd, bʌt ðə sɔɹd lʊkt əz bɹaɪtli ʃɑɹp əz ɛvɝ. hi tʌtʃt ði ɛdʒ wɪð ɪz θʌm, ðən heɪstəli stʌk ɪɾ ɪn ɪz maʊð. ðə bleɪd wɑz stɪl ɹeɪzɝ-ʃɑɹp.

When the shaft fell free, he looked at the sword blade in wonder. Even the best-sharpened axe would have dulled chopping through that hard, aged wood, but the sword looked as brightly sharp as ever. He touched the edge with his thumb, then hastily stuck it in his mouth. The blade was still razor-sharp.

bʌɾ i hæd noʊ taɪm fəɹ wʌndɝ. bloʊɪŋ aʊt ðə læntɝn - ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə hæv ðə bɑɹn bɝn daʊn ɑn tɑp ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls - hi ɡæðɝɾ ʌp ðə ʃæfs ən ɹæn bæk tə ɡɛt wʌɾ i hæd lɛft ət ðə haʊs.

But he had no time for wonder. Blowing out the lantern - there was no need to have the barn burn down on top of everything else - he gathered up the shafts and ran back to get what he had left at the house.

ɔltəɡɛðɝ ɪt meɪɾ ən ɑkwɝd bɝɾən. nɑɾ ə hɛvi wʌn, bʌt hɑɹd tə bæləns ən mænədʒ, ðə kɑɹt ʃæfs ʃɪftɪŋ ən twɪstɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz əz i stʌmbəld əkɹɔs ðə plaʊd fild. wʌns bæk ɪn ðə fɔɹəs ðeɪ wɝ ivən wɝs, kætʃɪŋ ɑn tʃɹiz ən nɑkɪŋ ɪm hæf ɔf ɪz fit. ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn iziɝ tə dʒɹæɡ, bʌt ðət wəd liv ə klɪɹ tʃɹeɪl bɪhaɪn hɪm. hi ɪntɛndəd tə weɪɾ əz lɔŋ əz pɑsəbəl bɪfɔɹ duɪŋ ðæt.

Altogether it made an awkward burden. Not a heavy one, but hard to balance and manage, the cart shafts shifting and twisting in his arms as he stumbled across the plowed field. Once back in the forest they were even worse, catching on trees and knocking him half off his feet. They would have been easier to drag, but that would leave a clear trail behind him. He intended to wait as long as possible before doing that.

tæm wɑz ɹaɪt wɛɹ i hæd lɛf hɪm, simɪŋli əslip. hi hoʊpt ɪt wɑz slip. sʌɾənli fɪɹfəl, hi dʒɹɑpt ɪz bɝɾənz ən pʊɾ ə hæn tə hɪz fɑðɝz feɪs. tæm stɪl bɹiðd, bʌt ðə fivɝ wɑz wɝs.

Tam was right where he had left him, seemingly asleep. He hoped it was sleep. Suddenly fearful, he dropped his burdens and put a hand to his father's face. Tam still breathed, but the fever was worse.

ðə tʌtʃ ɹaʊz tæm, bʌɾ oʊnli ɪndə ə heɪzi weɪkfəlnəs. "ɪz ðət ju, bɔɪ?" hi bɹiðd. "wɝiɾ əbaʊt ju. dʒɹimz ə deɪz ɡɔn. naɪtmɛɹz." mɝmɝɪŋ sɔfli, hi dʒɹɪftəɾ ɔf əɡɛn.

The touch roused Tam, but only into a hazy wakefulness. "Is that you, boy?" he breathed. "Worried about you. Dreams of days gone. Nightmares." Murmuring softly, he drifted off again.

"doʊnt wɝi," ɹænd sɛd. hi leɪ tæmz koʊɾ ən kloʊk oʊvɝ ɪm tə kip ɔf ðə wɪnd. "aɪl ɡɛt jə tə nɪneɪiv dʒʌst əz kwɪk əz aɪ kæn." əz i wɛn ɑn, əz mʌtʃ tə ɹiəʃʊɹ hɪmsɛlf əz fəɹ tæmz bɛnəfɪt, hi pild ɔf ɪz blʌdsteɪnd ʃɝt, hɑɹdli ivən noʊɾɪsɪŋ ðə koʊld ɪn ɪz heɪs tə bi ɹɪɾ ʌv ɪt, ən hɝidli pʊld ɑn ðə klin wʌn. θɹoʊɪŋ ɪz oʊld ʃɝɾ əweɪ meɪɾ ɪm fil əz ɪf i hæd dʒʌs hæɾ ə bæθ. "wil bi seɪf ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ ɪn noʊ taɪm, ən ðə wɪzdəm wɪl sɛɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɹaɪt. jəl si. ɛvɹiθɪŋz gɑnə bi ɔl ɹaɪt."

"Don't worry," Rand said. He lay Tam's coat and cloak over him to keep off the wind. "I'll get you to Nynaeve just as quick as I can." As he went on, as much to reassure himself as for Tam's benefit, he peeled off his bloodstained shirt, hardly even noticing the cold in his haste to be rid of it, and hurriedly pulled on the clean one. Throwing his old shirt away made him feel as if he had just had a bath. "We'll be safe in the village in no time, and the Wisdom will set everything right. You'll see. Everything's going to be all right."

ðət θɔt wɑz laɪk ə bikən əz i pʊld ɑn ɪz koʊɾ ən bɛn tə tɛn tæmz waʊnd. ðeɪ wəd bi seɪf wʌns ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə vɪlədʒ, ən nɪneɪiv wəd kjʊɹ tæm. hi dʒʌs hæd tə ɡɛɾ ɪm ðɛɹ.

That thought was like a beacon as he pulled on his coat and bent to tend Tam's wound. They would be safe once they reached the village, and Nynaeve would cure Tam. He just had to get him there.


tʃæptɝ sɪks


CHAPTER 6

ðə wɛstwʊd


The Westwood

ɪn ðə munlaɪt ɹænd kəd nɑt ɹɪli si wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ, bʌt tæmz waʊn sim tə bi oʊnli ə ʃæloʊ ɡæʃ əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪbz, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ðən ðə pɑm ə hɪz hænd. hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif. hi hæd sin ɪz fɑðɝ teɪk mɔɹ ʌv ən ɪnʒɝi ðən ðəɾ ən nɑɾ ivən stɑp wɝk ɪksɛp tə wɑʃ ɪɾ ɔf. heɪstəli hi sɝtʃt tæm fɹəm hɛd tə fʊt fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ bæɾ ɪnʌf tə əkaʊn fəɹ ðə fivɝ, bʌt ðə wʌn kʌt wɑz ɔl i kəd faɪnd.

In the moonlight Rand could not really see what he was doing, but Tam's wound seemed to be only a shallow gash along the ribs, no longer than the palm of his hand. He shook his head in disbelief. He had seen his father take more of an injury than that and not even stop work except to wash it off. Hastily he searched Tam from head to foot for something bad enough to account for the fever, but the one cut was all he could find.

smɔl əz ɪt wɑz, ðət loʊn kʌt wɑz stɪl ɡɹeɪv ɪnʌf; ðə flɛʃ ɝaʊn ɪt bɝn tə ðə tʌtʃ. ɪt wɑz ivən hɑɾɝ ðən ðə ɹɛst ə tæmz bɑɾi, ən ðə ɹɛst ə hɪm wɑz hɑɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɹændz dʒɔz klɛntʃ. ə skɔldɪŋ fivɝ laɪk ðət kəd kɪl, əɹ liv ə mæn ə hʌsk ʌv wʌɾ i hæd wʌns bɪn. hi soʊkt ə klɔθ wɪð wɔɾɝ fɹəm ðə skɪn ən leɪɾ ɪɾ əkɹɔs tæmz fɔɹhɛd.

Small as it was, that lone cut was still grave enough; the flesh around it burned to the touch. It was even hotter than the rest of Tam's body, and the rest of him was hot enough to make Rand's jaws clench. A scalding fever like that could kill, or leave a man a husk of what he had once been. He soaked a cloth with water from the skin and laid it across Tam's forehead.

hi tʃɹaɪd tə bi dʒɛntəl əbaʊt wɑʃɪŋ ən bændeɪdʒɪŋ ðə ɡæʃ ɑn ɪz fɑðɝz ɹɪbz, bʌt sɑft ɡɹoʊnz stɪl ɪntɝʌptɪd tæmz loʊ mʌɾɝɪŋ. stɑɹk bɹæntʃəz lumd ɝaʊn ðɛm, θɹɛɾənɪŋ əz ðeɪ ʃɪftəɾ əz ɪn ðə wɪnd. ʃʊɹli ðə tʃɹɑləks wəd ɡoʊ ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ wən ðeɪ feɪl tə faɪn tæm ən hɪm, wən ðeɪ keɪm bæk tə ðə fɑɹmhaʊs ən faʊn ɪt stɪl ɛmpti. hi tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk hɪmsɛlf bɪliv ɪt, bʌt ðə wɔntən dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ət ðə haʊs, ðə sɛnsləsnəs ʌv ɪt, lɛf lɪɾəl ɹum fəɹ bɪlif ə ðət sɔɹt. bɪlivɪŋ ðeɪ wəd ɡɪv ʌp ʃɔɹɾ ə kɪlɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðeɪ kəd faɪnd wɑz deɪnʒɝəs, ə fulɪʃ tʃæns i kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd tə teɪk.

He tried to be gentle about washing and bandaging the gash on his father's ribs, but soft groans still interrupted Tam's low muttering. Stark branches loomed around them, threatening as they shifted as in the wind. Surely the Trollocs would go on their way when they failed to find Tam and him, when they came back to the farmhouse and found it still empty. He tried to make himself believe it, but the wanton destruction at the house, the senselessness of it, left little room for belief of that sort. Believing they would give up short of killing everyone and everything they could find was dangerous, a foolish chance he could not afford to take.

tʃɹɑləks. laɪɾ əbʌv, tʃɹɑləks! kɹitʃɝz aʊɾ ʌv ə ɡlimənz teɪl kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə naɪt tə bæʃ ɪn ðə dɔɹ. ən ə feɪd. laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn mi, ə feɪd!

Trollocs. Light above, Trollocs! Creatures out of a gleeman's tale coming out of the night to bash in the door. And a Fade. Light shine on me, a Fade!

əbɹʌpli hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ði əntaɪɾ ɛnz ə ðə bændɪdʒ ɪn moʊʃənləs hænz. fɹoʊzən laɪk ə ɹæbət ðæts sin ə hɔks ʃædoʊ, hi θɔt skɔɹnfəli. wɪð ən æŋɡɹi ʃeɪk ə hɪz hɛɾ i fɪnɪʃt taɪɪŋ ðə bændɪdʒ ɝaʊn tæmz tʃɛst.

Abruptly he realized he was holding the untied ends of the bandage in motionless hands. Frozen like a rabbit that's seen a hawk's shadow, he thought scornfully. With an angry shake of his head he finished tying the bandage around Tam's chest.

noʊɪŋ wʌɾ i hæd tə du, ivən ɡɛɾɪŋ ɑn wɪð ɪt, dɪd nɑt stɑp ɪm biɪŋ əfɹeɪd. wən ðə tʃɹɑləks keɪm bæk ðeɪ wəd ʃʊɹli bɪɡɪn sɝtʃɪŋ ðə fɔɹəst ɝaʊn ðə fɑɹm fəɹ səm tʃɹeɪs ə ðə pipəl u hæɾ ɪskeɪp ðɛm. ðə bɑɾi ʌv ðə wʌn i hæd kɪld wəd tɛl əm ðoʊz pipəl wɝ nɑt fɑɹ ɔf. hu nu wʌɾ ə feɪd wəd du, əɹ kəd du? ɑn tɑp ə ðæt, hɪz fɑðɝz kɑmɛn əbaʊt tʃɹɑləks' hɪɹɪŋ wɑz əz laʊɾ ɪn ɪz maɪn əz ɪf tæm hæd dʒʌst sɛɾ ɪt. hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɹɪzɪstɪŋ ði ɝdʒ tə pʊɾ ə hæn oʊvɝ tæmz maʊθ, tə stɪl ɪz ɡɹoʊnz ən mɝmɝz. səm tʃɹæk baɪ sɛnt. wʌt kən aɪ də əbaʊt ðæt? nʌθɪŋ. hi kəd nɑt weɪs taɪm wɝiɪŋ oʊvɝ pɹɑbləmz i kəd də nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt.

Knowing what he had to do, even getting on with it, did not stop him being afraid. When the Trollocs came back they would surely begin searching the forest around the farm for some trace of the people who had escaped them. The body of the one he had killed would tell them those people were not far off. Who knew what a Fade would do, or could do? On top of that, his father's comment about Trollocs' hearing was as loud in his mind as if Tam had just said it. He found himself resisting the urge to put a hand over Tam's mouth, to still his groans and murmurs. Some track by scent. What can I do about that? Nothing. He could not waste time worrying over problems he could do nothing about.

"ju hæv tə kip kwaɪət," hi wɪspɝɾ ɪn ɪz fɑðɝz ɪɹ. "ðə tʃɹɑləks wɪl bi bæk."

"You have to keep quiet," he whispered in his father's ear. "The Trollocs will be back."

tæm spoʊk ɪn hʌʃt, hɔɹs toʊnz. "jɔɹ stɪl lʌvli, kɛɹi. stɪl lʌvli əz ə ɡɝl."

Tam spoke in hushed, hoarse tones. "You're still lovely, Kari. Still lovely as a girl."

ɹænd ɡɹɪməst. hɪz mʌðɝ hæd bɪn dɛd fɪftin jɪɹz. ɪf tæm bɪlivd ʃi wɑz stɪl əlaɪv, ðən ðə fivɝ wɑz ivən wɝs ðən ɹænd hæd θɔt. haʊ kəɾ i bi kɛp fɹəm spikɪŋ, naʊ ðət saɪləns maɪt min laɪf?

Rand grimaced. His mother had been dead fifteen years. If Tam believed she was still alive, then the fever was even worse than Rand had thought. How could he be kept from speaking, now that silence might mean life?

"mʌðɝ wɑns jə tə bi kwaɪət," ɹænd wɪspɝd. hi pɔz tə klɪɹ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ʌv ə sʌɾən taɪtnəs. ʃi hæd hæd dʒɛntəl hænz; hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət mʌtʃ. "kɛɹi wɑns jə tə bi kwaɪət. hɪɹ. dʒɹɪŋk."

"Mother wants you to be quiet," Rand whispered. He paused to clear his throat of a sudden tightness. She had had gentle hands; he remembered that much. "Kari wants you to be quiet. Here. Drink."

tæm ɡʌlp θɝstəli fɹəm ðə wɔɾɝskɪn, bʌɾ æftɝ ə fju swɑloʊz i tɝn ɪz hɛɾ əsaɪɾ ən bɪɡæn mɝmɝɪŋ sɔfli əɡɛn, tu loʊ fəɹ ɹænd tə ʌndɝstænd. hi hoʊpt ɪt wɑz tu loʊ tə bi hɝd baɪ hʌntɪŋ tʃɹɑləks, tu.

Tam gulped thirstily from the waterskin, but after a few swallows he turned his head aside and began murmuring softly again, too low for Rand to understand. He hoped it was too low to be heard by hunting Trollocs, too.

heɪstəli hi ɡɑɾ ɑn wɪð wʌt wɑz niɾəd. θɹi ʌv ðə blæŋkəts i woʊv ɝaʊn ən bɪtwin ðə ʃæfs kʌt fɹəm ðə kɑɹt, kɑntʃɹaɪvɪŋ ə meɪkʃɪf lɪɾɝ. hi wəɾ oʊnli bi eɪbəl tə kæɹi wʌn ɛnd, lɛɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝ dʒɹæɡ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, bʌɾ ɪt wəɾ əv tə du. fɹəm ðə læs blæŋkəɾ i kʌɾ ə lɔŋ stʃɹɪp wɪð ɪz bɛl naɪf, ðən taɪd wʌn ɛn ə ðə stʃɹɪp tə itʃ ə ðə ʃæfs.

Hastily he got on with what was needed. Three of the blankets he wove around and between the shafts cut from the cart, contriving a makeshift litter. He would only be able to carry one end, letting the other drag on the ground, but it would have to do. From the last blanket he cut a long strip with his belt knife, then tied one end of the strip to each of the shafts.

əz dʒɛnli əz i kʊd, hi lɪftəd tæm ɑntu ðə lɪɾɝ, wɪnsɪŋ wɪð ɛvɹi moʊn. hɪz fɑðɝ hæɾ ɔlweɪz simd ɪndəstʃɹʌktɪbəl. nʌθɪŋ kəd hɑɹm hɪm; nʌθɪŋ kəd stɑp hɪm, əɹ ivən sloʊ hɪm daʊn. fəɹ ɪm tə bi ɪn ðɪs kəndɪʃən ɔlmoʊst ɹɑbd ɹænd ʌv wʌt kɝədʒ i hæd mænədʒ tə ɡæðɝ. bʌɾ i hæd tə kip ɑn. ðət wɑz ɔl ðət kɛpt ɪm muvɪŋ. hi hæd tə.

As gently as he could, he lifted Tam onto the litter, wincing with every moan. His father had always seemed indestructible. Nothing could harm him; nothing could stop him, or even slow him down. For him to be in this condition almost robbed Rand of what courage he had managed to gather. But he had to keep on. That was all that kept him moving. He had to.

wən tæm faɪnəli leɪ ɑn ðə lɪɾɝ, ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən tʊk ðə sɔɹd bɛl fɹəm ɪz fɑðɝz weɪst. wən i fæsən ɪɾ ɝaʊn hɪmsɛlf, ɪt fɛlt ɑd ðɛɹ; ɪt meɪɾ ɪm fil ɑd. bɛlt ən ʃiθ ən sɔɹd təɡɛðɝ oʊnli weɪɾ ə fju paʊnz, bʌt wən i ʃiðd ðə bleɪɾ ɪt sim tə dʒɹæɡ əɾ ɪm laɪk ə ɡɹeɪt weɪt.

When Tam finally lay on the litter, Rand hesitated, then took the sword belt from his father's waist. When he fastened it around himself, it felt odd there; it made him feel odd. Belt and sheath and sword together only weighed a few pounds, but when he sheathed the blade it seemed to drag at him like a great weight.

æŋɡɹəli hi bɪɹeɪɾɪd hɪmsɛlf. ðɪs wɑz noʊ taɪm əɹ pleɪs fəɹ fulɪʃ fænsiz. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə bɪɡ naɪf. haʊ mɛni taɪmz hæɾ i deɪdʒɹimd əbaʊt wɛɹɪŋ ə sɔɹɾ ən hævɪŋ ædvɛntʃɝz? ɪf i kəd kɪl wʌn tʃɹɑlɑk wɪð ɪt, hi kəd ʃʊɹli faɪɾ ɔf ɛni ʌðɝz əz wɛl. oʊnli, hi nu ɔl tu wɛl ðət wʌt hæd hæpən ɪn ðə fɑɹmhaʊs hæd bɪn ðə pjʊɹəs lʌk. ən ɪz deɪdʒɹim ædvɛntʃɝz hæd nɛvɝ ɪnkluɾəd ɪz tiθ tʃæɾɝɪŋ, əɹ ɹʌnɪŋ fəɹ ɪz laɪf θɹu ðə naɪt, əɹ ɪz fɑðɝ ət ðə pɔɪn ə dɛθ.

Angrily he berated himself. This was no time or place for foolish fancies. It was only a big knife. How many times had he daydreamed about wearing a sword and having adventures? If he could kill one Trolloc with it, he could surely fight off any others as well. Only, he knew all too well that what had happened in the farmhouse had been the purest luck. And his daydream adventures had never included his teeth chattering, or running for his life through the night, or his father at the point of death.

heɪstəli hi tʌk ðə læs blæŋkəɾ ɝaʊn tæm, ən leɪd ðə wɔɾɝskɪn ən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə klɔθs bɪsaɪɾ ɪz fɑðɝ ɑn ðə lɪɾɝ. wɪð ə dip bɹɛθ i nɛl bɪtwin ðə ʃæfs ən lɪftəd ðə stʃɹɪp ə blæŋkəɾ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. ɪt sɛɾəld əkɹɔs ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹmz. wən i ɡɹɪp ðə ʃæfs ən stʃɹeɪɾənd, moʊst ə ðə weɪt wɑz ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. ɪt dɪd nɑt sim laɪk vɛɹi mʌtʃ. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ə smuð peɪs, hi sɛɾ aʊt fəɹ ɛmənz fild, ðə lɪɾɝ skɹeɪpɪŋ əlɔŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm.

Hastily he tucked the last blanket around Tam, and laid the waterskin and the rest of the cloths beside his father on the litter. With a deep breath he knelt between the shafts and lifted the strip of blanket over his head. It settled across his shoulders and under his arms. When he gripped the shafts and straightened, most of the weight was on his shoulders. It did not seem like very much. Trying to keep a smooth pace, he set out for Emond's Field, the litter scraping along behind him.

hi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə meɪk ɪz weɪ tə ðə kwɔɹi ɹoʊɾ ən fɑloʊ ðət tə ðə vɪlədʒ. ðə deɪnʒɝ wəɾ ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli bi ɡɹeɪɾɝ əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊd, bʌt tæm wəd ɹəsiv noʊ hɛlp əɾ ɔl ɪf i ɡɑɾ əm lɔs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ɪz weɪ θɹu ðə wʊdz ən ðə dɑɹk.

He had already decided to make his way to the Quarry Road and follow that to the village. The danger would almost certainly be greater along the road, but Tam would receive no help at all if he got them lost trying to find his way through the woods and the dark.

ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs i wɑz ɔlmoʊst aʊɾ ɑntu ðə kwɔɹi ɹoʊd bɪfɔɹ i nu ɪt. wən i ɹilaɪzd wɛɹ i wɑz, hɪz θɹoʊt taɪɾənd laɪk ə fɪst. hɝidli hi tɝn ðə lɪɾɝ ɝaʊn ən dʒɹæɡd ɪt bæk ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz ə weɪ, ðən stɑp tə kætʃ ɪz bɹɛθ ən lɛɾ ɪz hɑɹt stɑp paʊndɪŋ. stɪl pæntɪŋ, hi tɝn ist, təwɔɹɾ ɛmənz fild.

In the darkness he was almost out onto the Quarry Road before he knew it. When he realized where he was, his throat tightened like a fist. Hurriedly he turned the litter around and dragged it back into the trees a way, then stopped to catch his breath and let his heart stop pounding. Still panting, he turned east, toward Emond's Field.

tʃɹævlɪŋ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz wɑz mɔɹ dɪfəkəl ðən teɪkɪŋ tæm daʊn ðə ɹoʊd, ən ðə naɪt ʃʊɹli dɪd nɑt hɛlp, bʌt ɡoʊɪŋ aʊɾ ɑntu ðə ɹoʊɾ ɪtsɛlf wəd bi mædnəs. ði aɪdiə wɑz tə ɹitʃ ðə vɪlədʒ wɪθaʊt miɾɪŋ ɛni tʃɹɑləks; wɪθaʊɾ ivən siɪŋ ɛni, ɪf i hæɾ ɪz wɪʃ. hi hæd tə əsum ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ stɪl hʌntɪŋ ðɛm, ən sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ðeɪ wəd ɹilaɪz ðə tu hæd sɛɾ ɔf fəɹ ðə vɪlədʒ. ðət wɑz ðə moʊs laɪkli pleɪs tə ɡoʊ, ən ðə kwɔɹi ɹoʊd ðə moʊs laɪkli ɹut. ɪn tʃɹuθ, hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf kloʊsɝ tə ðə ɹoʊd ðən i laɪkt. ðə naɪɾ ən ðə ʃædoʊz ʌndɝ ðə tʃɹiz simd ɑfli bɛɹ kʌvɝ ɪn wɪtʃ tə haɪd fɹəm ði aɪz ʌv ɛniwʌn tʃɹævlɪŋ əlɔŋ ɪt.

Traveling through the trees was more difficult than taking Tam down the road, and the night surely did not help, but going out onto the road itself would be madness. The idea was to reach the village without meeting any Trollocs; without even seeing any, if he had his wish. He had to assume the Trollocs were still hunting them, and sooner or later they would realize the two had set off for the village. That was the most likely place to go, and the Quarry Road the most likely route. In truth, he found himself closer to the road than he liked. The night and the shadows under the trees seemed awfully bare cover in which to hide from the eyes of anyone traveling along it.

munlaɪt fɪltɝɪŋ θɹu bɛɹ bɹæntʃəz ɡeɪv oʊnli ɪnʌf ɪluməneɪʃən tə ful ɪz aɪz ɪndə θɪŋkɪŋ ðeɪ sɔ wʌt wɑz ʌndɝfʊt. ɹuts θɹɛɾənd tə tʃɹɪp ɪm əɾ ɛvɹi stɛp, oʊl bɹæmbəlz snæɡd ɪz lɛɡz, ən sʌɾən dɪps əɹ ɹaɪzəz ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊn hæɾ ɪm hæf fɔlɪŋ əz ɪz fʊt mɛt nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ɛɹ wɛɹ i ɪkspɛktəd fɝm ɝθ, əɹ stʌmbəlɪŋ wən ɪz toʊ stʃɹʌk dɝt waɪl stɪl muvɪŋ fɔɹwɝd. tæmz mʌɾɝɪŋz bɹoʊk ɪndə ə ʃɑɹp ɡɹoʊn wɛnɛvɝ wʌn ə ðə ʃæfs bʌmp tu kwɪkli oʊvɝ ɹuɾ əɹ ɹɑk.

Moonlight filtering through bare branches gave only enough illumination to fool his eyes into thinking they saw what was underfoot. Roots threatened to trip him at every step, old brambles snagged his legs, and sudden dips or rises in the ground had him half falling as his foot met nothing but air where he expected firm earth, or stumbling when his toe struck dirt while still moving forward. Tam's mutterings broke into a sharp groan whenever one of the shafts bumped too quickly over root or rock.

ənsɝɾənti meɪɾ ɪm pɪɹ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs əntɪl ɪz aɪz bɝnd, lɪsən əz i hæd nɛvɝ lɪsən bɪfɔɹ. ɛvɹi skɹeɪp ə bɹæntʃ əɡɛns bɹæntʃ, ɛvɹi ɹʌsəl ə paɪn niɾəlz, bɹɔɾ ɪm tə ə hɔlt, ɪɹz stʃɹeɪnɪŋ, hɑɹdli dɛɹɪŋ tə bɹið fəɹ fɪɹ i maɪt nɑt hɪɹ səm wɔɹnɪŋ saʊnd, fəɹ fɪɹ i maɪt hɪɹ ðət saʊnd. oʊnli wən i wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðə wɪnd wəɾ i ɡoʊ ɑn.

Uncertainty made him peer into the darkness until his eyes burned, listen as he had never listened before. Every scrape of branch against branch, every rustle of pine needles, brought him to a halt, ears straining, hardly daring to breathe for fear he might not hear some warning sound, for fear he might hear that sound. Only when he was sure it was just the wind would he go on.

sloʊli wɪɹinəs kɹɛpt ɪndə hɪz ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz, dʒɹɪvən hoʊm baɪ ə naɪt wɪn ðət mɑkt ɪz kloʊk ən koʊt. ðə weɪɾ ə ðə lɪɾɝ, soʊ lɪɾəl ət ðə stɑɹt, naʊ tʃɹaɪd tə pʊl ɪm tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hɪz stʌmbəlz wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɔl fɹəm tʃɹɪpɪŋ. ði ɔlmoʊs kɑnstən stʃɹʌɡəl nɑt tə fɔl tʊk əz mʌtʃ aʊɾ ə hɪm əz dɪd ði æktʃəwəl wɝk ə pʊlɪŋ ðə lɪɾɝ. hi hæd bɪn ʌp bɪfɔɹ dɔn tə bɪɡɪn ɪz tʃɔɹz, ən ivən wɪð ðə tʃɹɪp tə ɛmənz fild i hæd dʌn ɔlmoʊst ə fʊl deɪz wɝk. ɑn ɛni nɔɹməl naɪɾ i wəd bi ɹɛstɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə faɪɝpleɪs, ɹɛɾɪŋ wʌn ə tæmz smɔl kəlɛkʃən ə bʊks bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə bɛd. ðə ʃɑɹp tʃɪl soʊkt ɪndə hɪz boʊnz, ən ɪz stʌmək ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ðəɾ i hæd hæd nʌθɪŋ tə it sɪns mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹz hʌnikeɪks.

Slowly weariness crept into his arms and legs, driven home by a night wind that mocked his cloak and coat. The weight of the litter, so little at the start, now tried to pull him to the ground. His stumbles were no longer all from tripping. The almost constant struggle not to fall took as much out of him as did the actual work of pulling the litter. He had been up before dawn to begin his chores, and even with the trip to Emond's Field he had done almost a full day's work. On any normal night he would be resting before the fireplace, reading one of Tam's small collection of books before going to bed. The sharp chill soaked into his bones, and his stomach reminded him that he had had nothing to eat since Mistress al'Vere's honeycakes.

hi mʌɾɝd tə hɪmsɛlf, æŋɡɹi ət nɑt teɪkɪŋ səm fuɾ ət ðə fɑɹm. ə fju mɪnəts mɔɹ kəd nɑɾ əv meɪɾ ɛni dɪfɝəns. ə fju mɪnəts tə faɪn səm bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz. ðə tʃɹɑləks wəd nɑɾ əv kʌm bæk ɪn dʒʌst ə fju mɪnəts mɔɹ. əɹ dʒʌs ðə bɹɛd. ʌv kɔɹs, mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ wəɾ ɪnsɪst ɑn pʊɾɪŋ ə hɑt mil ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm wʌns ðeɪ ɹitʃt ði ɪn. ə stimɪŋ pleɪɾ ə hɝ θɪk læm stu, pɹɑbli. ən səm ə ðət bɹɛd ʃi hæd bɪn beɪkɪŋ. ən lɑts ə hɑt ti.

He muttered to himself, angry at not taking some food at the farm. A few minutes more could not have made any difference. A few minutes to find some bread and cheese. The Trollocs would not have come back in just a few minutes more. Or just the bread. Of course, Mistress al'Vere would insist on putting a hot meal in front of him once they reached the inn. A steaming plate of her thick lamb stew, probably. And some of that bread she had been baking. And lots of hot tea.

"ðeɪ keɪm oʊvɝ ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl laɪk ə flʌd," tæm sɛd sʌɾənli, ɪn ə stʃɹɔŋ, æŋɡɹi vɔɪs, "ænd wɑʃt ðə lænd wɪð blʌd. haʊ mɛni daɪd fəɹ leɪmənz sɪn?"

"They came over the Dragonwall like a flood," Tam said suddenly, in a strong, angry voice, "and washed the land with blood. How many died for Laman's sin?"

ɹænd ɔlmoʊs fɛl fɹəm sɝpɹaɪz. wɛɹəli hi loʊɝd ðə lɪɾɝ tə ðə ɡɹaʊn ən əntæŋɡəl hɪmsɛlf. ðə stʃɹɪp ə blæŋkət lɛft ə bɝnɪŋ ɡɹuv ɪn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. ʃɹʌɡɪŋ tə wɝk ðə nɑts aʊt, hi nɛl bɪsaɪd tæm. fʌmbəlɪŋ fəɹ ðə wɔɾɝbæɡ, hi pɪɹd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ veɪnli ɪn ðə dɪm munlaɪt tə si ʌp ən daʊn ðə ɹoʊd, nɑt twɛnti peɪsɪz əweɪ. nʌθɪŋ muv ðəɹ bʌt ʃædoʊz. nʌθɪŋ bʌt ʃædoʊz.

Rand almost fell from surprise. Wearily he lowered the litter to the ground and untangled himself. The strip of blanket left a burning groove in his shoulders. Shrugging to work the knots out, he knelt beside Tam. Fumbling for the waterbag, he peered through the trees, trying vainly in the dim moonlight to see up and down the road, not twenty paces away. Nothing moved there but shadows. Nothing but shadows.

"ðɛɹ ɪzən ɛni flʌɾ ə tʃɹɑləks, fɑðɝ. nɑt naʊ, ɛniweɪ. wɪl bi seɪf ɪn ɛmənz fil sun. dʒɹɪŋk ə lɪɾəl wɔɾɝ."

"There isn't any flood of Trollocs, father. Not now, anyway. We'll be safe in Emond's Field soon. Drink a little water."

tæm bɹʌʃt əsaɪd ðə wɔɾɝbæɡ wɪð ən ɑɹm ðət sim tə hæv ɹiɡeɪn ɔl ʌv ɪts stʃɹɛŋkθ. hi sizd ɹændz kɑlɝ, pʊlɪŋ ɪm kloʊs ɪnʌf tə fil ðə hiɾ ə hɪz fɑðɝz fivɝ ɪn ɪz oʊn tʃik. "ðeɪ kɔld əm sævədʒəz," tæm sɛɾ ɝdʒənli. "ðə fulz sɛd ðeɪ kəd bi swɛpt əsaɪd laɪk ɹʌbɪʃ. haʊ mɛni bæɾəlz lɔst, haʊ mɛni sɪɾiz bɝnd, bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ feɪs ðə tʃɹuθ? bɪfɔɹ ðə neɪʃənz stʊd təɡɛðɝ əɡɛns ðɛm?" hi lust ɪz hoʊld ɑn ɹænd, ən sædnəs fɪld ɪz vɔɪs. "ðə fild ət mɛɹəθ kɑɹpəɾɪd wɪð ðə dɛd, ən noʊ saʊn bʌt ðə kɹaɪz ə ɹeɪvənz ən ðə bʌzɪŋ ə flaɪz. ðə tɑpləs taʊɝz ə kɛɹhin bɝnɪŋ ɪn ðə naɪt laɪk tɔɹtʃɪz. ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz ðeɪ bɝn ən slu bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ tɝn bæk. ɔl ðə weɪ tə - "

Tam brushed aside the waterbag with an arm that seemed to have regained all of its strength. He seized Rand's collar, pulling him close enough to feel the heat of his father's fever in his own cheek. "They called them savages," Tam said urgently. "The fools said they could be swept aside like rubbish. How many battles lost, how many cities burned, before they faced the truth? Before the nations stood together against them?" He loosed his hold on Rand, and sadness filled his voice. "The field at Marath carpeted with the dead, and no sound but the cries of ravens and the buzzing of flies. The topless towers of Cairhien burning in the night like torches. All the way to the Shining Walls they burned and slew before they were turned back. All the way to - "

ɹænd klæmpt ə hæn oʊvɝ ɪz fɑðɝz maʊð. ðə saʊn keɪm əɡɛn, ə ɹɪðmɪk θəɾɪŋ, dɝɛkʃənləs ɪn ðə tʃɹiz, feɪɾɪŋ ðən ɡɹoʊɪŋ stʃɹɔŋɝ əɡɛn əz ðə wɪnd ʃɪftəd. fɹaʊnɪŋ, hi tɝn ɪz hɛd sloʊli, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪsaɪd fɹəm wɛɹ ɪt keɪm. ə flɪkɝ ə moʊʃən kɑt ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, ən ɪn ən ɪnstən i wɑz kɹaʊtʃt oʊvɝ tæm. hi wɑz stɑɹɾəld tə fil ðə hɪlt ə ðə sɔɹd klʌtʃt taɪɾ ɪn ɪz hænd, bʌt moʊst ə hɪm kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn ðə kwɔɹi ɹoʊɾ əz ɪf ðə ɹoʊd wɝ ði oʊnli ɹil θɪŋ ɪn ði ɪntaɪɝ wɝld.

Rand clamped a hand over his father's mouth. The sound came again, a rhythmic thudding, directionless in the trees, fading then growing stronger again as the wind shifted. Frowning, he turned his head slowly, trying to decide from where it came. A flicker of motion caught the corner of his eye, and in an instant he was crouched over Tam. He was startled to feel the hilt of the sword clutched tight in his hand, but most of him concentrated on the Quarry Road as if the road were the only real thing in the entire world.

weɪvɝɪŋ ʃædoʊz tə ði ist sloʊli ɹizɑlv ðɛmsɛlvz ɪndə ə hɔɹs ən ɹaɪɾɝ fɑloʊɾ ʌp ðə ɹoʊd baɪ tɔl, bʌlki ʃeɪps tʃɹɑɾɪŋ tə kip ʌp wɪð ði ænəməl. ðə peɪl laɪɾ ə ðə mun ɡlɪɾɝd fɹəm spɪɹhɛdz ən æks bleɪdz. ɹænd nɛvɝ ivən kənsɪɾɝd ðət ðeɪ maɪt bi vɪlɪdʒɝz kʌmɪŋ tə hɛlp. hi nu wʌt ðeɪ wɝ. hi kəd fil ɪt, laɪk ɡɹɪt skɹeɪpɪŋ ɪz boʊnz, ivən bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ dʒɹu kloʊs ɪnʌf fəɹ munlaɪt tə ɹɪvil ðə hʊɾɪd kloʊk swɑðɪŋ ðə hɔɹsmən, ə kloʊk ðət hʌŋ ʌndɪstɝbd baɪ ðə wɪnd. ɔl ə ðə ʃeɪps əpɪɹd blæk ɪn ðə naɪt, ən ðə hɔɹsəz hʊvz meɪd ðə seɪm saʊnz ðəɾ ɛni ʌðɝz wʊd, bʌt ɹænd nu ðɪs hɔɹs fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ.

Wavering shadows to the east slowly resolved themselves into a horse and rider followed up the road by tall, bulky shapes trotting to keep up with the animal. The pale light of the moon glittered from spearheads and axe blades. Rand never even considered that they might be villagers coming to help. He knew what they were. He could feel it, like grit scraping his bones, even before they drew close enough for moonlight to reveal the hooded cloak swathing the horseman, a cloak that hung undisturbed by the wind. All of the shapes appeared black in the night, and the horse's hooves made the same sounds that any other's would, but Rand knew this horse from any other.

bɪhaɪn ðə dɑɹk ɹaɪɾɝ keɪm naɪtmɛɹ fɔɹmz wɪð hɔɹnz ən mʌzəlz ən biks, tʃɹɑləks ɪn ə dʌbəl faɪl, ɔl ɪn stɛps, buts ən hʊvz stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊn ət ðə seɪm ɪnstən əz ɪf oʊbeɪɪŋ ə sɪŋɡəl maɪnd. ɹænd kaʊntəd twɛnti əz ðeɪ ɹæn pæst. hi wʌndɝd wʌt kaɪndə mæn wəd dɛɹ tɝn ɪz bæk ɑn soʊ mɛni tʃɹɑləks. əɹ ɑn wʌn, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ.

Behind the dark rider came nightmare forms with horns and muzzles and beaks, Trollocs in a double file, all in steps, boots and hooves striking the ground at the same instant as if obeying a single mind. Rand counted twenty as they ran past. He wondered what kind of man would dare turn his back on so many Trollocs. Or on one, for that matter.

ðə tʃɹɑɾɪŋ kɑləm dɪsəpɪɹd wɛstwɝd, θʌmpɪŋ fʊtfɔlz feɪɾɪŋ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs, bʌt ɹænd ɹɪmeɪnd wɛɹ i wɑz, nɑt muvɪŋ ə mʌsəl ɪksɛp tə bɹið. sʌmθɪŋ toʊld ɪm tə bi sɝɾən, æbsəlutli sɝɾən, ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ i muvd. ət lɔŋ læst i dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ ən bɪɡæn tə stʃɹeɪɾən.

The trotting column disappeared westward, thumping footfalls fading into the darkness, but Rand remained where he was, not moving a muscle except to breathe. Something told him to be certain, absolutely certain, they were gone before he moved. At long last he drew a deep breath and began to straighten.

ðɪs taɪm ðə hɔɹs meɪd noʊ saʊn əɾ ɔl. ɪn ɪɹi saɪləns ðə dɑɹk ɹaɪɾɝ ɹɪtɝnd, hɪz ʃæɾoʊi maʊn stɑpɪŋ ɛvɹi fju stɛps əz ɪt wɔk sloʊli bæk daʊn ðə ɹoʊd. ðə wɪnd ɡʌstɪd haɪɝ, moʊnɪŋ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz; ðə hɔɹsmənz kloʊk leɪ stɪl əz dɛθ. wɛnɛvɝ ðə hɔɹs hɔltəd, ðət hʊɾɪd hɛd swʌŋ fɹəm saɪd tə saɪɾ əz ðə ɹaɪɾɝ pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst, sɝtʃɪŋ. ɪɡzækli ɑpəzət ɹænd ðə hɔɹs stɑpt əɡɛn, ðə ʃæɾoʊd oʊpənɪŋ ə ðə hʊd tɝnɪŋ təwɔɹd wɛɹ i kɹaʊtʃt əbʌv ɪz fɑðɝ.

This time the horse made no sound at all. In eerie silence the dark rider returned, his shadowy mount stopping every few steps as it walked slowly back down the road. The wind gusted higher, moaning through the trees; the horseman's cloak lay still as death. Whenever the horse halted, that hooded head swung from side to side as the rider peered into the forest, searching. Exactly opposite Rand the horse stopped again, the shadowed opening of the hood turning toward where he crouched above his father.

ɹændz hæn taɪɾənd kənvʌlsɪvli ɑn ðə sɔɹd hɪlt. hi fɛl ðə ɡeɪz, dʒʌst əz i hæd ðət mɔɹnɪŋ, ən ʃɪvɝɾ əɡɛn fɹəm ðə heɪtʃɹəɾ ivən ɪf i kəd nɑt si ɪt. ðət ʃɹaʊɾɪd mæn heɪɾəd ɛvɹiwʌn ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət lɪvd. dɪspaɪt ðə koʊld wɪnd, swɛt biɾɪd ɑn ɹændz feɪs.

Rand's hand tightened convulsively on the sword hilt. He felt the gaze, just as he had that morning, and shivered again from the hatred even if he could not see it. That shrouded man hated everyone and everything, everything that lived. Despite the cold wind, sweat beaded on Rand's face.

ðən ðə hɔɹs wɑz muvɪŋ ɑn, ə fju saʊnləs stɛps ən stɑp, əntɪl ɔl ɹænd kəd si wɑz ə bɛɹli dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃəbəl blɝ ɪn ðə naɪt fɑɹ daʊn ðə ɹoʊd. ɪt cʊɾə bɪn ɛniθɪŋ, bʌɾ i hæd nɑt teɪkən ɪz aɪz ɔf ɪt fəɹ ə sɛkənd. ɪf i lɔst ɪt, hi wɑz əfɹeɪd ðə nɛks taɪm i sɔ ðə blæk-kloʊkt ɹaɪɾɝ maɪt bi wən ðət saɪlən hɔɹs wɑz ɑn tɑp ə hɪm.

Then the horse was moving on, a few soundless steps and stop, until all Rand could see was a barely distinguishable blur in the night far down the road. It could have been anything, but he had not taken his eyes off it for a second. If he lost it, he was afraid the next time he saw the black-cloaked rider might be when that silent horse was on top of him.

əbɹʌpli ðə ʃædoʊ wɑz ɹʌʃɪŋ bæk, pæsɪŋ ɪm ɪn ə saɪlənt ɡæləp. ðə ɹaɪɾɝ lʊkt oʊnli əhɛɾ ə hɪm əz i spɛd wɛstwɝɾ ɪndə ðə naɪt, təwɔɹd ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst. təwɔɹd ðə fɑɹm.

Abruptly the shadow was rushing back, passing him in a silent gallop. The rider looked only ahead of him as he sped westward into the night, toward the Mountains of Mist. Toward the farm.

ɹænd sæɡd, ɡʌlpɪŋ ɛɹ ən skɹʌbɪŋ koʊl swɛɾ ɔf ɪz feɪs wɪð ɪz sliv. hi dɪd nɑt kɛɹ ɛni mɔɹ əbaʊt waɪ ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd kʌm. ɪf i nɛvɝ faʊn aʊt waɪ, ðət wəd bi faɪn, dʒʌst əz lɔŋ əz ɪt wɑz ɔl ɛndəd.

Rand sagged, gulping air and scrubbing cold sweat off his face with his sleeve. He did not care any more about why the Trollocs had come. If he never found out why, that would be fine, just as long as it was all ended.

wɪð ə ʃeɪk i ɡæðɝd hɪmsɛlf, heɪstəli tʃɛkɪŋ ɪz fɑðɝ. tæm wɑz stɪl mɝmɝɪŋ, bʌt soʊ sɔfli ɹænd kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt ðə wɝdz. hi tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɪv ɪm ə dʒɹɪŋk, bʌt ðə wɔɾɝ spɪld oʊvɝ ɪz fɑðɝz tʃɪn. tæm kɔft ən tʃoʊkt ɑn ðə tʃɹɪkəl ðət meɪɾ ɪɾ ɪndə hɪz maʊθ, ðən bɪɡæn mʌɾɝɪŋ əɡɛn əz ɪf ðəɹ hæd nɑt bɪn ɛni ɪntɝʌpʃən.

With a shake he gathered himself, hastily checking his father. Tam was still murmuring, but so softly Rand could not make out the words. He tried to give him a drink, but the water spilled over his father's chin. Tam coughed and choked on the trickle that made it into his mouth, then began muttering again as if there had not been any interruption.

ɹænd splæʃt ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ wɔɾɝ ɑn ðə klɔθ ɑn tæmz fɔɹhɛd, pʊʃt ðə wɔɾɝbæɡ bæk ɑn ðə lɪɾɝ, ən skɹæmbəl bɪtwin ðə ʃæfs əɡɛn.

Rand splashed a little more water on the cloth on Tam's forehead, pushed the waterbag back on the litter, and scrambled between the shafts again.

hi stɑɹɾəd aʊɾ əz ɪf i hæd hæɾ ə ɡʊd naɪts slip, bʌt ðə nu stʃɹɛŋkθ dɪd nɑt læs lɔŋ. fɪɹ mæskt ɪz taɪɹədnəs ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, bʌt ðoʊ ðə fɪɹ ɹɪmeɪnd, ðə mæsk mɛltəɾ əweɪ kwɪkli. sun i wɑz bæk tə stʌmbəlɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ hʌŋɡɝ ən eɪkɪŋ mʌsəlz. hi kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn pʊɾɪŋ wʌn fʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ʌðɝ wɪθaʊt tʃɹɪpɪŋ.

He started out as if he had had a good night's sleep, but the new strength did not last long. Fear masked his tiredness in the beginning, but though the fear remained, the mask melted away quickly. Soon he was back to stumbling forward, trying to ignore hunger and aching muscles. He concentrated on putting one foot in front of the other without tripping.

ɪn ɪz maɪn i pɪktʃɝɾ ɛmənz fild, ʃʌɾɝz θɹoʊn bæk ən ðə haʊsəz lɪt fəɹ wɪntɝnaɪt, pipəl ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɡɹiɾɪŋz əz ðeɪ pæs bæk ən fɔɹθ ɑn ðɛɹ vɪzəts, fɪɾəlz fɪlɪŋ ðə stʃɹits wɪð "jeɪɛmz fɑli" ən "hɛɹən ɑn ðə wɪŋ." hɹəl luhən wəɾ əv wʌn tu mɛni bɹændiz ən stɑɹt sɪŋɪŋ "ðə wɪn ɪn ðə bɑɹli" ɪn ə vɔɪs laɪk ə bʊlfɹɑɡ - hi ɔlweɪz dɪd - əntɪl ɪz waɪf mænədʒ tə ʃʌʃ hɪm, ən sɛn bui wəd dɪsaɪd tə pɹuv i kəd stɪl dæns əz wɛl əz ɛvɝ, ən mæt wəɾ əv sʌmθɪŋ plæn ðət wəd nɑt kwaɪt hæpən ðə weɪ hi ɪntɛndəd, ən ɛvɹibɑɾi wəd noʊ hi wɑz ɹispɑnsəbəl ivən ɪf noʊ wʌn kəd pɹuv ɪt. hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst smaɪl θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt haʊ ɪt wəd bi.

In his mind he pictured Emond's Field, shutters thrown back and the houses lit for Winternight, people shouting greetings as they passed back and forth on their visits, fiddles filling the streets with "Jaem's Folly" and "Heron on the Wing." Haral Luhhan would have one too many brandies and start singing "The Wind in the Barley" in a voice like a bullfrog - he always did - until his wife managed to shush him, and Cenn Buie would decide to prove he could still dance as well as ever, and Mat would have something planned that would not quite happen the way he intended, and everybody would know he was responsible even if no one could prove it. He could almost smile thinking about how it would be.

æftɝ ə taɪm tæm spoʊk ʌp əɡɛn.

After a time Tam spoke up again.

"ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə. ɪts sɛɾ ɪt meɪks noʊ sid, bʌt ðeɪ bɹɔɾ ə kʌɾɪŋ tə kɛɹhin, ə sæpəlɪŋ. ə ɹɔɪəl ɡɪft ʌv wʌndɝ fəɹ ðə kɪŋ." ðoʊ hi saʊndəɾ æŋɡɹi, hi wɑz bɛɹli laʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɹænd tə ʌndɝstænd. ɛniwʌn u kəd hɪɹ ɪm wəd bi eɪbəl tə hɪɹ ðə lɪɾɝ skɹeɪpɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊnd, tu. ɹænd kɛpt ɑn, oʊnli hæf lɪsnɪŋ. "ðeɪ nɛvɝ meɪk pis. nɛvɝ. bʌt ðeɪ bɹɔɾ ə sæpəlɪŋ, əz ə saɪn ə pis. faɪv hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ɪt ɡɹu. faɪv hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ə pis wɪð ðoʊz u meɪk noʊ pis wɪð stʃɹeɪnʒɝz. waɪ dɪɾ i kʌɾ ɪt daʊn? waɪ? blʌd wɑz ðə pɹaɪs fəɹ ɑvɛndɔɹɑldɛɹə. blʌd ðə pɹaɪs fəɹ leɪmənz pɹaɪd." hi feɪɾəd ɔf ɪndə mʌɾɝɪŋ wʌns mɔɹ.

"Avendesora. It's said it makes no seed, but they brought a cutting to Cairhien, a sapling. A royal gift of wonder for the king." Though he sounded angry, he was barely loud enough for Rand to understand. Anyone who could hear him would be able to hear the litter scraping across the ground, too. Rand kept on, only half listening. "They never make peace. Never. But they brought a sapling, as a sign of peace. Five hundred years it grew. Five hundred years of peace with those who make no peace with strangers. Why did he cut it down? Why? Blood was the price for Avendoraldera. Blood the price for Laman's pride." He faded off into muttering once more.

taɪɹədli ɹænd wʌndɝd wʌt fivɝ-dʒɹim tæm kəd bi hævɪŋ naʊ. ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə. ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf wɑz səpoʊz tə hæv ɔl sɔɹts ə mɝækjələs kwɑləɾiz, bʌt nʌn ə ðə stɔɹiz mɛnʃən ɛni sæpəlɪŋ, əɹ ɛni "ðeɪ." ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə wʌn, ən ðət bɪlɔŋ tə ðə ɡɹin mæn.

Tiredly Rand wondered what fever-dream Tam could be having now. Avendesora. The Tree of Life was supposed to have all sorts of miraculous qualities, but none of the stories mentioned any sapling, or any "they." There was only the one, and that belonged to the Green Man.

oʊnli ðət mɔɹnɪŋ i maɪɾ əv fɛl fulɪʃ ət mjuzɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə ɡɹin mæn ən ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf. ðeɪ wɝ oʊnli stɔɹiz. ɑɹ ðeɪ? tʃɹɑləks wɝ dʒʌst stɔɹiz ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. meɪbi ɔl ðə stɔɹiz wɝ əz ɹil əz ðə nuz ðə pɛdlɝz ən mɝtʃəns bɹɔɾ ɔl ðə ɡlimənz teɪlz ən ɔl ðə stɔɹiz toʊld ət naɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. nɛkst i maɪɾ æktʃəli  mit ðə ɡɹin mæn, əɹ ən oʊɡiɝ dʒaɪənt, əɹ ə waɪld, blæk-veɪld ilmən.

Only that morning he might have felt foolish at musing over the Green Man and the Tree of Life. They were only stories. Are they? Trollocs were just stories this morning. Maybe all the stories were as real as the news the peddlers and merchants brought all the gleeman's tales and all the stories told at night in front of the fireplace. Next he might actually meet the Green Man, or an Ogier giant, or a wild, black-veiled Aielman.

tæm wɑz tɔkɪŋ əɡɛn, hi ɹilaɪzd, səmtaɪmz oʊnli mɝmɝɪŋ, səmtaɪmz laʊɾ ɪnʌf tə ʌndɝstænd. fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm i stɑp tə pæn fəɹ bɹɛθ, ðən wɛn ɑn əz ɪf i θɔɾ i hæd bɪn spikɪŋ ðə hoʊl taɪm.

Tam was talking again, he realized, sometimes only murmuring, sometimes loud enough to understand. From time to time he stopped to pant for breath, then went on as if he thought he had been speaking the whole time.

". . . bæɾəlz ɑɹ ɔlweɪz hɑt, ivən ɪn ðə snoʊ. swɛt hit. blʌd hit. oʊnli dɛθ ɪz kul. sloʊp ə ðə maʊntən . . . oʊnli pleɪs dɪdn stɪŋk ə dɛθ. hæd tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm smɛl ʌv ɪt . . . saɪɾ ʌv ɪt. . . . hɝɾ ə beɪbi kɹaɪ. ðɛɹ wɪmən faɪɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə mɛn, səmtaɪmz, bʌt waɪ ðeɪ hæd lɛɾ əɹ kʌm, aɪ doʊnt . . . ɡeɪv bɝθ ðəɹ əloʊn, bɪfɔɹ ʃi daɪɾ ə hɝ wunz. . . . kʌvɝd ðə tʃaɪld wɪð əɹ kloʊk, bʌt ðə wɪnd . . . bloʊn ðə kloʊk əweɪ. . . . tʃaɪld, blu wɪð ðə koʊld. ʃʊɾə bɪn dɛd, tu. . . . kɹaɪɪŋ ðɛɹ. kɹaɪɪŋ ɪn ðə snoʊ. aɪ kʊdn dʒʌs liv ə tʃaɪld. . . . noʊ tʃɪlʒɹən ʌv əɹ oʊn. . . . ɔlweɪz nu jə wɑntəd tʃɪlʒɹən. aɪ nu jud teɪk ɪt tə jəɹ hɑɹt, kɛɹi. jɛs, læs. ɹænd ɪz ə ɡʊd neɪm. ə ɡʊd neɪm."

". . . battles are always hot, even in the snow. Sweat heat. Blood heat. Only death is cool. Slope of the mountain . . . only place didn't stink of death. Had to get away from smell of it . . . sight of it. . . . heard a baby cry. Their women fight alongside the men, sometimes, but why they had let her come, I don't . . . gave birth there alone, before she died of her wounds. . . . covered the child with her cloak, but the wind . . . blown the cloak away. . . . child, blue with the cold. Should have been dead, too. . . . crying there. Crying in the snow. I couldn't just leave a child. . . . no children of our own. . . . always knew you wanted children. I knew you'd take it to your heart, Kari. Yes, lass. Rand is a good name. A good name."

sʌɾənli ɹændz lɛɡz lɔs ðə lɪɾəl stʃɹɛŋkθ ðeɪ hæd. stʌmbəlɪŋ, hi fɛl tə hɪz niz. tæm moʊnd wɪð ðə dʒoʊlt, ən ðə stʃɹɪp ə blæŋkət kʌɾ ɪndə ɹændz ʃoʊldɝz, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑɾ əwɛɹ ʌv iðɝ. ɪf ə tʃɹɑlɑk hæd lɛpt ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ɹaɪt ðɛn, hi wəd dʒʌst əv stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪt. hi lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət tæm, hu hæd sʌŋk bæk ɪndə wɝdləs mɝmɝz. fivɝ-dʒɹimz, hi θɔt dʌli. fivɝz ɔlweɪz bɹɔt bæd dʒɹimz, ən ðɪs wɑz ə naɪt fəɹ naɪtmɛɹz ivən wɪθaʊɾ ə fivɝ.

Suddenly Rand's legs lost the little strength they had. Stumbling, he fell to his knees. Tam moaned with the jolt, and the strip of blanket cut into Rand's shoulders, but he was not aware of either. If a Trolloc had leaped up in front of him right then, he would just have stared at it. He looked over his shoulder at Tam, who had sunk back into wordless murmurs. Fever-dreams, he thought dully. Fevers always brought bad dreams, and this was a night for nightmares even without a fever.

"ju ɑɹ maɪ fɑðɝ," hi sɛɾ əlaʊd, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ bæk ə hæn tə tʌtʃ tæm, "æn aɪm - " ðə fivɝ wɑz wɝs. mʌtʃ wɝs.

"You are my father," he said aloud, stretching back a hand to touch Tam, "and I am - " The fever was worse. Much worse.

ɡɹɪmli hi stʃɹʌɡəl tə hɪz fit. tæm mɝmɝd sʌmθɪŋ, bʌt ɹænd ɹəfjuz tə lɪsən tə ɛni mɔɹ. θɹoʊɪŋ ɪz weɪɾ əɡɛns ði ɪmpɹəvaɪz hɑɹnəs i tʃɹaɪd tə pʊɾ ɔl ə hɪz maɪn ɪndə teɪkɪŋ wʌn lɛɾən stɛp æftɝ ənʌðɝ, ɪndə ɹitʃɪŋ ðə seɪfti ʌv ɛmənz fild. bʌɾ i kəd nɑt stɑp ði ɛkoʊ ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪnd. hiz maɪ fɑðɝ. ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə fivɝ-dʒɹim. hiz maɪ fɑðɝ. ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə fivɝ-dʒɹim. laɪt, hu æm aɪ?

Grimly he struggled to his feet. Tam murmured something, but Rand refused to listen to any more. Throwing his weight against the improvised harness he tried to put all of his mind into taking one leaden step after another, into reaching the safety of Emond's Field. But he could not stop the echo in the back of his mind. He's my father. It was just a fever-dream. He's my father. It was just a fever-dream. Light, who am I?


tʃæptɝ sɛvən


CHAPTER 7

aʊɾ ə ðə wʊdz


Out of the Woods

ɡɹeɪ fɝs laɪt keɪm waɪl ɹænd stɪl tʃɹʌdʒ θɹu ðə fɔɹəst. ət fɝst i dɪd nɑt ɹɪli si. wən i faɪnəli dɪd, hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə feɪɾɪŋ dɑɹknəs ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɪz aɪz toʊl hɪm, hi kəd hɑɹdli bɪliv i hæd spɛn ɔl naɪt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃɹævəl ðə dɪstəns fɹəm ðə fɑɹm tə ɛmənz fild. ʌv kɔɹs, ðə kwɔɹi ɹoʊd baɪ deɪ, ɹɑks ən ɔl, wɑz ə fɑɹ kɹaɪ fɹəm ðə wʊdz baɪ naɪt. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, ɪt sim deɪz sɪns i hæd sin ðə blæk-kloʊkt ɹaɪɾɝ ɑn ðə ɹoʊd, wiks sɪns i ən tæm hæd ɡɔn ɪn fəɹ ðɛɹ sʌpɝ. hi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fɛl ðə stʃɹɪp ə klɔθ dɪɡɪŋ ɪndə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz, bʌt ðən i fɛl nʌθɪŋ ɪn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ɪksɛp nʌmnəs, nɔɹ ɪn ɪz fit, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. ɪn bɪtwin, ɪt wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ. hɪz bɹɛθ keɪm ɪn leɪbɝd pæns ðət hæd lɔŋ sɪns sɛɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ən lʌŋz tə bɝnɪŋ, ən hʌŋɡɝ twɪstəɾ ɪz stʌmək ɪndə kwizi sɪknəs.

Gray first light came while Rand still trudged through the forest. At first he did not really see. When he finally did, he stared at the fading darkness in surprise. No matter what his eyes told him, he could hardly believe he had spent all night trying to travel the distance from the farm to Emond's Field. Of course, the Quarry Road by day, rocks and all, was a far cry from the woods by night. On the other hand, it seemed days since he had seen the black-cloaked rider on the road, weeks since he and Tam had gone in for their supper. He no longer felt the strip of cloth digging into his shoulders, but then he felt nothing in his shoulders except numbness, nor in his feet, for that matter. In between, it was another matter. His breath came in labored pants that had long since set his throat and lungs to burning, and hunger twisted his stomach into queasy sickness.

tæm hæd fɔlən saɪlən səm taɪm bɪfɔɹ. ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ lɔŋ ɪt hæd bɪn sɪns ðə mɝmɝz sist, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt dɛɹ hɔl naʊ tə tʃɛk ɑn tæm. ɪf i stɑpt i wəd nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə stɑɹɾ aʊɾ əɡɛn. ɛniweɪ, wʌtɛvɝ tæmz kəndɪʃən, hi kəd də nʌθɪŋ bɪɑnd wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ. ði oʊnli hoʊp leɪ əhɛd, ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ. hi tʃɹaɪd wɛɹəli tə ɪnkɹis ɪz peɪs, bʌɾ ɪz wʊɾən lɛɡz kəntɪnjud ðɛɹ sloʊ plɑd. hi bɛɹli ivən noʊɾəst ðə koʊld, əɹ ðə wɪnd.

Tam had fallen silent some time before. Rand was not sure how long it had been since the murmurs ceased, but he did not dare halt now to check on Tam. If he stopped he would never be able to force himself to start out again. Anyway, Whatever Tam's condition, he could do nothing beyond what he was doing. The only hope lay ahead, in the village. He tried wearily to increase his pace, but his wooden legs continued their slow plod. He barely even noticed the cold, or the wind.

veɪɡli hi kɑt ðə smɛl ʌv wʊdzmoʊk. ət list i wɑz ɔlmoʊs ðəɹ ɪf i kəd smɛl ðə vɪlədʒ tʃɪmniz. ə taɪɝd smaɪl hæɾ oʊnli bɪɡʌn ɑn ɪz feɪs, ðoʊ, wən ɪt tɝn tə ə fɹaʊn. smoʊk leɪ hɛvi ɪn ði ɛɹ - tu hɛvi. wɪð ðə wɛðɝ, ə faɪɝ maɪt wɛl bi bleɪzɪŋ ɑn ɛvɹi hɑɹθ ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ, bʌt ðə smoʊk wɑz stɪl tu stʃɹɔŋ. ɪn ɪz maɪn i sɔ əɡɛn ðə tʃɹɑləks ɑn ðə ɹoʊd. tʃɹɑləks kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ði ist, fɹəm ðə dɝɛkʃən ʌv ɛmənz fild. hi pɪɹɾ əhɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk aʊt ðə fɝs haʊsəz, ən ɹɛɾi tə ʃaʊt fəɹ hɛlp ət ðə fɝst saɪɾ ʌv ɛniwʌn, ivən sɛn bui əɹ wʌn ə ðə kɑplɪnz. ə smɔl vɔɪs ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd toʊld ɪm tə hoʊp sʌmwʌn ðəɹ kəd stɪl ɡɪv hɛlp.

Vaguely he caught the smell of woodsmoke. At least he was almost there if he could smell the village chimneys. A tired smile had only begun on his face, though, when it turned to a frown. Smoke lay heavy in the air - too heavy. With the weather, a fire might well be blazing on every hearth in the village, but the smoke was still too strong. In his mind he saw again the Trollocs on the road. Trollocs coming from the east, from the direction of Emond's Field. He peered ahead, trying to make out the first houses, and ready to shout for help at the first sight of anyone, even Cenn Buie or one of the Coplins. A small voice in the back of his head told him to hope someone there could still give help.

sʌɾənli ə haʊs bɪkeɪm vɪzəbəl θɹu ðə læs bɛɹ-bɹæntʃt tʃɹiz, ən ɪt wɑz ɔl i kəd də tə kip ɪz fit muvɪŋ. hoʊp tɝnɪŋ tə ʃɑɹp dɪspɛɹ, hi stæɡɝɾ ɪndə ðə vɪlədʒ.

Suddenly a house became visible through the last bare-branched trees, and it was all he could do to keep his feet moving. Hope turning to sharp despair, he staggered into the village.

tʃɑɹd paɪlz ə ɹʌbəl stʊɾ ɪn ðə pleɪsəz ə hæf ðə haʊsəz ʌv ɛmənz fild. sʊt-koʊɾəd bɹɪk tʃɪmniz θɹʌs laɪk dɝɾi fɪŋɡɝz fɹəm hips ə blækən tɪmbɝz. θɪn wɪsps ə smoʊk stɪl ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə ɹuənz. ɡɹaɪmi-feɪs vɪlɪdʒɝz, səm jɛɾ ɪn ðɛɹ naɪt kloʊðz, poʊk θɹu ði æʃəz, hɪɹ pʊlɪŋ fɹi ə kʊkpɑt, ðəɹ sɪmpli pɹɑɾɪŋ fɔɹlɔɹnli ət ðə ɹɛkədʒ wɪð ə stɪk. wʌt lɪɾəl hæd bɪn ɹɛskjud fɹəm ðə fleɪmz dɑɾəd ðə stʃɹits; tɔl mɪɹɝz ən pɑlɪʃt saɪdbɔɹdz ən haɪtʃəsts stʊɾ ɪn ðə dʌst əmʌŋ tʃɛɹz ən teɪbəlz bɛɹiɾ ʌndɝ bɛɾɪŋ, kʊkɪŋ jutɛnsəlz, ən miɡɝ paɪlz ə kloʊðɪŋ ən pɝsənəl bɪlɔŋɪŋz.

Charred piles of rubble stood in the places of half the houses of Emond's Field. Soot-coated brick chimneys thrust like dirty fingers from heaps of blackened timbers. Thin wisps of smoke still rose from the ruins. Grimy-faced villagers, some yet in their night clothes, poked through the ashes, here pulling free a cookpot, there simply prodding forlornly at the wreckage with a stick. What little had been rescued from the flames dotted the streets; tall mirrors and polished sideboards and highchests stood in the dust among chairs and tables buried under bedding, cooking utensils, and meager piles of clothing and personal belongings.

ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən sim skæɾɝd ət ɹændəm θɹu ðə vɪlədʒ. faɪv haʊsəz mɑɹtʃt əntʌtʃt ɪn wʌn ɹoʊ, waɪl ɪn ənʌðɝ pleɪs ə loʊn sɝvaɪvɝ stʊd sɝaʊndəd baɪ dɛsəleɪʃən.

The destruction seemed scattered at random through the village. Five houses marched untouched in one row, while in another place a lone survivor stood surrounded by desolation.

ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ wɔɾɝ, ðə θɹi hjudʒ bɛl taɪn bɑnfaɪɝz ɹɔɹd, tɛndəd baɪ ə klʌstɝ ə mɛn. θɪk kɑləmz ə blæk smoʊk bɛnt nɔɹθwɝd wɪð ðə wɪnd, flɛk baɪ kɛɹləs spɑɹks. wʌn ə mæstɝ ælvɪɹz dɝən stæljənz wɑz dʒɹæɡɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ ɹænd kəd nɑt meɪk aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə ɡɹaʊn təwɔɹd ðə wæɡən bɹɪdʒ, ən ðə fleɪmz.

On the far side of the Winespring Water, the three huge Bel Tine bonfires roared, tended by a cluster of men. Thick columns of black smoke bent northward with the wind, flecked by careless sparks. One of Master al'Vere's Dhurran stallions was dragging something Rand could not make out over the ground toward the Wagon Bridge, and the flames.

bɪfɔɹ i wɑz wɛl aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz, ə suɾi-feɪst hɹəl luhən hɝid tə hɪm, klʌtʃɪŋ ə wʊdzmənz æks ɪn wʌn θɪk-fɪŋɡɝd hænd. ðə bɝli blæksmɪθs æʃ-smɪɹd naɪtʃɝt hʌŋ tə hɪz buts, ði æŋɡɹi ɹɛd wɛlt ʌv ə bɝn əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst ʃoʊɪŋ θɹu ə ɹæɡəd tɛɹ. hi dʒɹɑp tə wʌn ni bɪsaɪd ðə lɪɾɝ. tæmz aɪz wɝ kloʊzd, ən ɪz bɹiðɪŋ keɪm loʊ ən hɑɹd.

Before he was well out of the trees, a sooty-faced Haral Luhhan hurried to him, clutching a woodsman's axe in one thick-fingered hand. The burly blacksmith's ash-smeared nightshirt hung to his boots, the angry red welt of a burn across his chest showing through a ragged tear. He dropped to one knee beside the litter. Tam's eyes were closed, and his breathing came low and hard.

"tʃɹɑləks, bɔɪ?" mæstɝ luhən æskt ɪn ə smoʊk-hɔɹs vɔɪs. "hɪɹ, tu. hɪɹ, tu. wɛl, wi meɪ hæv bɪn lʌkiɝ ðən ɛniwʌn əz ə ɹaɪt tə bi, ɪf jə kən kɹɛɾət ɪt. hi nidz ðə wɪzdəm. naʊ wɛɹ ɪn ðə laɪɾ ɪz ʃi? ɛɡwin!"

"Trollocs, boy?" Master Luhhan asked in a smoke-hoarse voice. "Here, too. Here, too. Well, we may have been luckier than anyone has a right to be, if you can credit it. He needs the Wisdom. Now where in the Light is she? Egwene!"

ɛɡwin, ɹʌnɪŋ baɪ wɪð əɹ ɑɹmz fʊl ə bɛdʃits tɔɹn ɪndə bændədʒəz, lʊkt ɝaʊn əɾ əm wɪθaʊt sloʊɪŋ. hɝ aɪz stɛɹɾ ət sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə fɑɹ dɪstəns; dɑɹk sɝkəlz meɪɾ əm əpɪɹ ivən lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ðeɪ æktʃəli  wɝ. ðən ʃi sɔ ɹænd ən stɑpt, dʒɹɔɪŋ ə ʃʌɾɝɪŋ bɹɛθ. "oʊ, noʊ, ɹænd, nɑt jəɹ fɑðɝ? ɪz i . . . ? kʌm, əl teɪk jə tə nɪneɪiv."

Egwene, running by with her arms full of bedsheets torn into bandages, looked around at them without slowing. Her eyes stared at something in the far distance; dark circles made them appear even larger than they actually were. Then she saw Rand and stopped, drawing a shuddering breath. "Oh, no, Rand, not your father? Is he . . . ? Come, I'll take you to Nynaeve."

ɹænd wɑz tu taɪɝd, tu stʌnd, tə spik. ɔl θɹu ðə naɪɾ ɛmənz fil hæd bɪn ə heɪvən, wɛɹ i ən tæm wəd bi seɪf. naʊ ɔl i kəd sim tə də wɑz stɛɹ ɪn dɪsmeɪ əɾ əɹ smoʊk-steɪn dʒɹɛs. hi noʊɾəst ɑd dɪteɪlz əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ vɛɹi ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ðə bʌɾənz daʊn ðə bæk ə hɝ dʒɹɛs wɝ dʌn ʌp kɹʊkədli. ən əɹ hænz wɝ klin. hi wʌndɝd waɪ hɝ hænz wɝ klin wən smʌdʒɪz ə sʊt mɑɹkt əɹ tʃiks.

Rand was too tired, too stunned, to speak. All through the night Emond's Field had been a haven, where he and Tam would be safe. Now all he could seem to do was stare in dismay at her smoke-stained dress. He noticed odd details as if they were very important. The buttons down the back of her dress were done up crookedly. And her hands were clean. He wondered why her hands were clean when smudges of soot marked her cheeks.

mæstɝ luhən sim tə ʌndɝstænd wʌt hæd kʌm oʊvɝ hɪm. leɪɪŋ ɪz æks əkɹɔs ðə ʃæfs, ðə blæksmɪθ pɪkt ʌp ðə ɹɪɹ ə ðə lɪɾɝ ən ɡeɪv ɪɾ ə dʒɛntəl pʊʃ, pɹɑɾɪŋ ɪm tə fɑloʊ ɛɡwin. hi stʌmbəld æftɝ əɹ əz ɪf wɔkɪŋ ɪn ɪz slip. bɹifli hi wʌndɝd haʊ mæstɝ luhən nu ðə kɹitʃɝz wɝ tʃɹɑləks, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə fliɾɪŋ θɔt. ɪf tæm kəd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðɛm, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən waɪ hɹəl luhən kəd nɑt.

Master Luhhan seemed to understand what had come over him. Laying his axe across the shafts, the blacksmith picked up the rear of the litter and gave it a gentle push, prodding him to follow Egwene. He stumbled after her as if walking in his sleep. Briefly he wondered how Master Luhhan knew the creatures were Trollocs, but it was a fleeting thought. If Tam could recognize them, there was no reason why Haral Luhhan could not.

"ɔl ðə stɔɹiz ɑɹ ɹil," hi mʌɾɝd.

"All the stories are real," he muttered.

"soʊ ɪt simz, læd," ðə blæksmɪθ sɛd. "soʊ ɪt simz."

"So it seems, lad," the blacksmith said. "So it seems."

ɹænd oʊnli hæf hɝd. hi wɑz kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɑn fɑloʊɪŋ ɛɡwinz slɛndɝ ʃeɪp. hi hæd pʊl hɪmsɛlf təɡɛðɝ dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə wɪʃ ʃi wəd hɝi, ðoʊ ɪn tʃɹuθ ʃi wɑz kipɪŋ əɹ peɪs tə wʌt ðə tu mɛn kəd mænədʒ wɪð ðɛɹ bɝɾən. ʃi lɛɾ əm hæfweɪ daʊn ðə ɡɹin, tə ðə kɔldɝ haʊs. tʃɑɹ blækən ði ɛdʒəz ʌv ɪts θætʃ, ən smʌt steɪn ðə waɪtwɑʃt wɔlz. ʌv ðə haʊsəz ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ oʊnli ðə faʊndeɪʃən stoʊnz wɝ lɛft, ən tu paɪlz ʌv æʃ ən bɝn tɪmbɝz. wʌn hæd bɪn ðə haʊs ə bɛɹɪn θeɪn, wʌn ə ðə mɪlɝz bɹʌðɝz. ði ʌðɝ hæd bɪn eɪbəl kɔθənz. mæts fɑðɝ. ivən ðə tʃɪmniz hæd tɑpəld.

Rand only half heard. He was concentrating on following Egwene's slender shape. He had pulled himself together just enough to wish she would hurry, though in truth she was keeping her pace to what the two men could manage with their burden. She led them halfway down the Green, to the Calder house. Char blackened the edges of its thatch, and smut stained the whitewashed walls. Of the houses on either side only the foundation stones were left, and two piles of ash and burned timbers. One had been the house of Berin Thane, one of the miller's brothers. The other had been Abell Cauthon's. Mat's father. Even the chimneys had toppled.

"weɪt hɪɹ," ɛɡwin sɛd, ən ɡeɪv əm ə lʊk əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ ən ænsɝ. wən ðeɪ oʊnli stʊd ðɛɹ, ʃi mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ, ðən dæʃt ɪnsaɪd.

"Wait here," Egwene said, and gave them a look as if expecting an answer. When they only stood there, she muttered something under her breath, then dashed inside.

"mæt," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪz i . . . ?"

"Mat," Rand said. "Is he . . . ?"

"hiz əlaɪv," ðə blæksmɪθ sɛd. hi sɛt daʊn ɪz ɛn ə ðə lɪɾɝ ən stʃɹeɪɾənd sloʊli. "aɪ sɔ hɪm ə lɪɾəl waɪl əɡoʊ. ɪts ə wʌndɝ ɛni ʌv əs ɑɹ əlaɪv. ðə weɪ ðeɪ keɪm æftɝ maɪ haʊs, ən ðə fɔɹdʒ, juɾ əv θɔɾ aɪ hæd ɡoʊld ən dʒuəlz ɪn ðɛɹ. ælsbɛt kɹækt wʌnz skʌl wɪð ə fɹaɪɪŋ pæn. ʃi tʊk wʌn lʊk ət ði æʃəz ʌv əɹ haʊs ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ ən sɛɾ aʊt hʌntɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə vɪlədʒ wɪð ðə bɪɡəs hæmɝ ʃi kəd dɪɡ aʊɾ ʌv wʌts lɛft ə ðə fɔɹdʒ, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs ɛni ʌv əm hɪɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ. aɪ kəɾ ɔlmoʊs pɪɾi ðə θɪŋ ɪf ʃi faɪnz wʌn." hi nɑɾəd tə ðə kɔldɝ haʊs. "mɪstʃɹəs kɔldɝ ən ə fju ʌðɝz tʊk ɪn səm ə ðoʊz u wɝ hɝt, ðə wʌnz wɪð noʊ hoʊm ə ðɛɹ oʊn stɪl stændɪŋ. wən ðə wɪzdəmz sin tæm, wɪl faɪn ɪm ə bɛd. ði ɪn, meɪbi. ðə meɪɝ ɔfɝɾ ɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi, bʌt nɪneɪiv sɛd ðə hɝt foʊk wəd hil bɛɾɝ ɪf ðəɹ wɝn soʊ mɛni ʌv əm təɡɛðɝ."

"He's alive," the blacksmith said. He set down his end of the litter and straightened slowly. "I saw him a little while ago. It's a wonder any of us are alive. The way they came after my house, and the forge, you'd have thought I had gold and jewels in there. Alsbet cracked one's skull with a frying pan. She took one look at the ashes of our house this morning and set out hunting around the village with the biggest hammer she could dig out of what's left of the forge, just in case any of them hid instead of running away. I could almost pity the thing if she finds one." He nodded to the Calder house. "Mistress Calder and a few others took in some of those who were hurt, the ones with no home of their own still standing. When the Wisdom's seen Tam, we'll find him a bed. The inn, maybe. The Mayor offered it already, but Nynaeve said the hurt folk would heal better if there weren't so many of them together."

ɹænd sæŋk tə hɪz niz. ʃɹʌɡɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz blæŋkət hɑɹnəs, hi wɛɹəli bɪzid hɪmsɛlf wɪð tʃɛkɪŋ tæmz kʌvɝz. tæm nɛvɝ muvd əɹ meɪɾ ə saʊnd, ivən wən ɹændz wʊɾən hænz dʒɑsəl hɪm. bʌɾ i wɑz stɪl bɹiðɪŋ, ət list. maɪ fɑðɝ. ði ʌðɝ wɑz dʒʌs ðə fivɝ tɔkɪŋ. "wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ kʌm bæk?" hi sɛd dʌli.

Rand sank to his knees. Shrugging out of his blanket harness, he wearily busied himself with checking Tam's covers. Tam never moved or made a sound, even when Rand's wooden hands jostled him. But he was still breathing, at least. My father. The other was just the fever talking. "What if they come back?" he said dully.

"ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz," mæstɝ luhən sɛɾ ənizəli. "ɪf ðeɪ kʌm bæk. . . . wɛl, ðəɹ ɡɔn, naʊ. soʊ wi pɪk ʌp ðə pisəz, bɪld ʌp wʌts bɪn tɔɹn daʊn." hi saɪd, hɪz feɪs ɡoʊɪŋ slæk əz i nʌkəl ðə smɔl ə hɪz bæk. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɹænd ɹilaɪz ðət ðə hɛvisɛt mæn wɑz əz taɪɝɾ əz i wɑz hɪmsɛlf, ɪf nɑt mɔɹ soʊ. ðə blæksmɪθ lʊkt ət ðə vɪlədʒ, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "aɪ doʊn səpoʊz tədeɪ wɪl bi mʌtʃ ʌv ə bɛl taɪn. bʌt wɪl meɪk ɪt θɹu. wi ɔlweɪz hæv." əbɹʌpli hi tʊk ʌp ɪz æks, ən ɪz feɪs fɝmd. "ðɛɹz wɝk weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ mi. doʊn jə wɝi, læd. ðə wɪzdəm wɪl teɪk ɡʊd kɛɹ ə hɪm, ən ðə laɪt wɪl teɪk kɛɹ ʌv əs ɔl. ən ɪf ðə laɪt dʌznt, wɛl, wɪl dʒʌs teɪk kɛɹ ʌv aʊɝsɛlvz. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, wɝ tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk."

"The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills," Master Luhhan said uneasily. "If they come back. . . . Well, they're gone, now. So we pick up the pieces, build up what's been torn down." He sighed, his face going slack as he knuckled the small of his back. For the first time Rand realized that the heavyset man was as tired as he was himself, if not more so. The blacksmith looked at the village, shaking his head. "I don't suppose today will be much of a Bel Tine. But we'll make it through. We always have." Abruptly he took up his axe, and his face firmed. "There's work waiting for me. Don't you worry, lad. The Wisdom will take good care of him, and the Light will take care of us all. And if the Light doesn't, well, we'll just take care of ourselves. Remember, we're Two Rivers folk."

stɪl ɑn ɪz niz, ɹænd lʊkt ət ðə vɪlədʒ əz ðə blæksmɪθ wɔkt əweɪ, ɹɪli lʊk fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. mæstɝ luhən wɑz ɹaɪt, hi θɔt, ən wɑz sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt sɝpɹaɪz baɪ wʌɾ i sɔ. pipəl stɪl dʌɡ ɪn ðə ɹuənz ə ðɛɹ hoʊmz, bʌɾ ivən ɪn ðə ʃɔɹt taɪm i hæd bɪn ðəɹ mɔɹ ə ðɛm hæd bɪɡʌn tə muv wɪð ə sɛns ə pɝpəs. hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil ðə ɡɹoʊɪŋ dɪtɝməneɪʃən. bʌɾ i wʌndɝd. ðeɪ hæd sin tʃɹɑləks; hæd ðeɪ sin ðə blæk-kloʊkt ɹaɪɾɝ? hæd ðeɪ fɛlt ɪz heɪtʃɹəd?

Still on his knees, Rand looked at the village as the blacksmith walked away, really looked for the first time. Master Luhhan was right, he thought, and was surprised that he was not surprised by what he saw. People still dug in the ruins of their homes, but even in the short time he had been there more of them had begun to move with a sense of purpose. He could almost feel the growing determination. But he wondered. They had seen Trollocs; had they seen the black-cloaked rider? Had they felt his hatred?

nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin əpɪɹd fɹəm ðə kɔldɝ haʊs, ən i spɹæŋ tə hɪz fit. əɹ ɹæðɝ, hi tʃɹaɪd tə spɹɪŋ tə hɪz fit; ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ʌv ə stʌmbəlɪŋ lɝtʃ ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs pʊɾ ɪm ɑn ɪz feɪs ɪn ðə dʌst.

Nynaeve and Egwene appeared from the Calder house, and he sprang to his feet. Or rather, he tried to spring to his feet; it was more of a stumbling lurch that almost put him on his face in the dust.

ðə wɪzdəm dʒɹɑp tə hɝ niz bɪsaɪd ðə lɪɾɝ wɪθaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə ɡlæns. hɝ feɪs ən dʒɹɛs wɝ ivən dɝɾiɝ ðən ɛɡwinz, ən ðə seɪm dɑɹk sɝkəlz laɪn əɹ aɪz, ðoʊ hɝ hænz, tu, wɝ klin. ʃi fɛl tæmz feɪs ən θʌmd oʊpən ɪz aɪlɪdz. wɪð ə fɹaʊn ʃi pʊl daʊn ðə kʌvɝɪŋz ən iz ðə bændɪdʒ əsaɪd tə lʊk ət ðə waʊnd. bɪfɔɹ ɹænd kəd si wʌt leɪ ʌndɝniθ ʃi hæd ɹipleɪs ðə wɑɾəd klɔθ. saɪɪŋ, ʃi smuðd ðə blæŋkəɾ ən kloʊk bæk ʌp tə tæmz nɛk wɪð ə dʒɛntəl tʌtʃ, əz ɪf tʌkɪŋ ə tʃaɪld ɪn fəɹ ðə naɪt.

The Wisdom dropped to her knees beside the litter without giving him so much as a glance. Her face and dress were even dirtier than Egwene's, and the same dark circles lined her eyes, though her hands, too, were clean. She felt Tam's face and thumbed open his eyelids. With a frown she pulled down the coverings and eased the bandage aside to look at the wound. Before Rand could see what lay underneath she had replaced the wadded cloth. Sighing, she smoothed the blanket and cloak back up to Tam's neck with a gentle touch, as if tucking a child in for the night.

"ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ aɪ kən du," ʃi sɛd. ʃi hæd tə pʊɾ əɹ hænz ɑn əɹ niz tə stʃɹeɪɾən ʌp. "aɪm sɑɹi, ɹænd."

"There's nothing I can do," she said. She had to put her hands on her knees to straighten up. "I'm sorry, Rand."

fəɹ ə moʊmən i stʊd, nɑɾ ʌndɝstændɪŋ, əz ʃi stɑɹɾəd bæk tə ðə haʊs, ðən i skɹæmbəld æftɝ əɹ ən pʊld əɹ ɝaʊn tə feɪs hɪm. "hiz daɪɪŋ," hi kɹaɪd.

For a moment he stood, not understanding, as she started back to the house, then he scrambled after her and pulled her around to face him. "He's dying," he cried.

"aɪ noʊ," ʃi sɛd sɪmpli, ən i sæɡd wɪð ðə mæɾɝ-ʌv-fæktnəs ʌv ɪt.

"I know," she said simply, and he sagged with the matter-of-factness of it.

"ju hæv tə də sʌmθɪŋ. juv tə. jəɹ ðə wɪzdəm."

"You have to do something. You have to. You're the Wisdom."

peɪn twɪstəɾ əɹ feɪs, bʌɾ oʊnli fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ðən ʃi wɑz ɔl hɑloʊ-aɪd ɹizɑlv əɡɛn, hɝ vɔɪs ɪmoʊʃənləs ən fɝm. "jɛs, aɪ æm. aɪ noʊ wʌɾ aɪ kən də wɪð maɪ mɛɾəsənz, ən aɪ noʊ wən ɪts tu leɪt. doʊn jə θɪŋk aɪ wəd də sʌmθɪŋ ɪf aɪ kʊd? bʌɾ aɪ kænt. aɪ kænt, ɹænd. ən ðəɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝz u nid mi. pipəl aɪ kən hɛlp."

Pain twisted her face, but only for an instant, then she was all hollow-eyed resolve again, her voice emotionless and firm. "Yes, I am. I know what I can do with my medicines, and I know when it's too late. Don't you think I would do something if I could? But I can't. I can't, Rand. And there are others who need me. People I can help."

"aɪ bɹɔɾ ɪm tə jə əz kwɪkli əz aɪ kʊd," hi mʌmbəld. ivən wɪð ðə vɪlədʒ ɪn ɹuənz, ðəɹ hæd bɪn ðə wɪzdəm fəɹ hoʊp. wɪð ðət ɡɔn, hi wɑz ɛmpti.

"I brought him to you as quickly as I could," he mumbled. Even with the village in ruins, there had been the Wisdom for hope. With that gone, he was empty.

"aɪ noʊ jə dɪd," ʃi sɛd dʒɛnli. ʃi tʌtʃt ɪz tʃik wɪð əɹ hænd. "ɪɾ ɪzən jəɹ fɔlt. jə dɪd ðə bɛst ɛniwʌn kʊd. aɪm sɑɹi, ɹænd, bʌɾ aɪ hæv ʌðɝz tə tɛn tə. əɹ tʃɹʌbəlz ɑɹ dʒʌs bɪɡɪnɪŋ, aɪm əfɹeɪd."

"I know you did," she said gently. She touched his cheek with her hand. "It isn't your fault. You did the best anyone could. I am sorry, Rand, but I have others to tend to. Our troubles are just beginning, I'm afraid."

veɪkənli hi stɛɹɾ æftɝ əɹ əntɪl ðə dɔɹ ə ðə haʊs kloʊz bɪhaɪn hɝ. hi kəd nɑt meɪk ɛni θɔt kʌm ɪksɛp ðət ʃi wəd nɑt hɛlp.

Vacantly he stared after her until the door of the house closed behind her. He could not make any thought come except that she would not help.

sʌɾənli hi wɑz nɑk bæk ə stɛp əz ɛɡwin kænən ɪndə hɪm, θɹoʊɪŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɪm. hɝ hʌɡ wɑz hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə bɹɪŋ ə ɡɹʌn fɹəm ɪm ɛni ʌðɝ taɪm; naʊ hi oʊnli lʊk saɪlənli ət ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪnd wɪtʃ ɪz hoʊps hæd vænɪʃt.

Suddenly he was knocked back a step as Egwene cannoned into him, throwing her arms around him. Her hug was hard enough to bring a grunt from him any other time; now he only looked silently at the door behind which his hopes had vanished.

"aɪm soʊ sɑɹi, ɹænd," ʃi sɛɾ əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst. "laɪt, aɪ wɪʃ ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ aɪ kəd du."

"I'm so sorry, Rand," she said against his chest. "Light, I wish there was something I could do."

nʌmbli hi pʊɾ ɪz ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝ. "aɪ noʊ. aɪ . . . aɪ hæv tə də sʌmθɪŋ, ɛɡwin. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt, bʌɾ aɪ kæn dʒʌs lɛt hɪm. . . ." hɪz vɔɪs bɹoʊk, ən ʃi hʌɡd ɪm hɑɹɾɝ.

Numbly he put his arms around her. "I know. I . . . I have to do something, Egwene. I don't know what, but I can't just let him. . . ." His voice broke, and she hugged him harder.

"ɛɡwin!" ət nɪneɪivz ʃaʊt fɹəm ðə haʊs, ɛɡwin dʒʌmpt. "ɛɡwin, aɪ nid ju! ən wɑʃ jəɹ hænz əɡɛn!"

"Egwene!" At Nynaeve's shout from the house, Egwene jumped. "Egwene, I need you! And wash your hands again!"

ʃi pʊʃt hɝsɛlf fɹi fɹəm ɹændz ɑɹmz. "ʃi nidz maɪ hɛlp, ɹænd."

She pushed herself free from Rand's arms. "She needs my help, Rand."

"ɛɡwin!"

"Egwene!"

hi θɔɾ i hɝɾ ə sɑb əz ʃi spʌn əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. ðən ʃi wɑz ɡɔn, ən i wɑz lɛft əloʊn bɪsaɪd ðə lɪɾɝ. fəɹ ə moʊmən i lʊk daʊn ət tæm, filɪŋ nʌθɪŋ bʌt hɑloʊ hɛlpləsnəs. sʌɾənli hɪz feɪs hɑɹɾənd. "ðə meɪɝ wɪl noʊ wʌt tə du," hi sɛd, lɪftɪŋ ðə ʃæfs wʌns mɔɹ. "ðə meɪɝ wɪl noʊ." bɹæn ælvɪɹ ɔlweɪz nu wʌt tə du. wɪð wɪɹi ɑbstənəsi hi sɛɾ aʊt fəɹ ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn.

He thought he heard a sob as she spun away from him. Then she was gone, and he was left alone beside the litter. For a moment he looked down at Tam, feeling nothing but hollow helplessness. Suddenly his face hardened. "The Mayor will know what to do," he said, lifting the shafts once more. "The Mayor will know." Bran al'Vere always knew what to do. With weary obstinacy he set out for the Winespring Inn.

ənʌðɝ ə ðə dɝən stæljənz pæs hɪm, ɪts hɑɹnəs stʃɹæps taɪɾ ɝaʊn ði æŋkəlz ʌv ə bɪɡ ʃeɪp dʒɹeɪpt wɪð ə dɝɾi blæŋkət. ɑɹmz kʌvɝd wɪð kɔɹs hɛɹ dʒɹæɡd ɪn ðə dɝt bɪhaɪn ðə blæŋkət, ən wʌn kɔɹnɝ wɑz pʊʃt ʌp tə ɹɪvil ə ɡoʊts hɔɹn. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɑz noʊ pleɪs fəɹ stɔɹiz tə bɪkʌm hɔɹəbli ɹil. ɪf tʃɹɑləks bɪlɔŋd ɛniwɛɹ ɪt wɑz ɪn ðə wɝld aʊtsaɪd, fəɹ pleɪsəz wɛɹ ðeɪ hæɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ən fɔls dʒɹæɡənz ən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wʌɾ ɛls kʌm tə laɪf aʊɾ ə ðə teɪlz ʌv ɡlimən. nɑt ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. nɑɾ ɛmənz fild.

Another of the Dhurran stallions passed him, its harness straps tied around the ankles of a big shape draped with a dirty blanket. Arms covered with coarse hair dragged in the dirt behind the blanket, and one corner was pushed up to reveal a goat's horn. The Two Rivers was no place for stories to become horribly real. If Trollocs belonged anywhere it was in the world outside, for places where they had Aes Sedai and false Dragons and the Light alone knew what else come to life out of the tales of gleemen. Not the Two Rivers. Not Emond's Field.

əz i meɪɾ ɪz weɪ daʊn ðə ɡɹin, pipəl kɔl tə hɪm, səm fɹəm ðə ɹuənz ə ðɛɹ hoʊmz, æskɪŋ ɪf ðeɪ kəd hɛlp. hi hɝɾ əm oʊnli əz mɝmɝz ɪn ðə bækɡɹaʊnd, ivən wən ðeɪ wɔkt əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɪm fəɹ ə dɪstəns əz ðeɪ spoʊk. wɪθaʊt ɹɪli θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪɾ i mænədʒd wɝdz ðət sɛɾ i niɾəd noʊ hɛlp, ðəɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz biɪŋ teɪkən kɛɹ ʌv. wən ðeɪ lɛf hɪm, wɪð wɝid lʊks, ən səmtaɪmz ə kɑmɛn əbaʊt sɛndɪŋ nɪneɪiv tə hɪm, hi noʊɾəst ðət dʒʌst əz lɪɾəl. ɔl i lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi əwɛɹ ʌv wɑz ðə pɝpəs i hæd fɪkst ɪn ɪz hɛd. bɹæn ælvɪɹ kəd də sʌmθɪŋ tə hɛlp tæm. wʌt ðət kəd bi hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə dwɛl ɑn. bʌt ðə meɪɝ wəd bi eɪbəl tə də sʌmθɪŋ, tə θɪŋk ə sʌmθɪŋ.

As he made his way down the Green, people called to him, some from the ruins of their homes, asking if they could help. He heard them only as murmurs in the background, even when they walked alongside him for a distance as they spoke. Without really thinking about it he managed words that said he needed no help, that everything was being taken care of. When they left him, with worried looks, and sometimes a comment about sending Nynaeve to him, he noticed that just as little. All he let himself be aware of was the purpose he had fixed in his head. Bran al'Vere could do something to help Tam. What that could be he tried not to dwell on. But the Mayor would be able to do something, to think of something.

ði ɪn hæɾ ɔlmoʊs kəmplitli ɪskeɪp ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ðət hæd teɪkən hæf ðə vɪlədʒ. ə fju skɔɹk mɑɹks mɑɹɾ ɪts wɔlz, bʌt ðə ɹɛd ɹuf taɪlz ɡlɪɾɝd ɪn ðə sʌnlaɪɾ əz bɹaɪtli əz ɛvɝ. ɔl ðət wɑz lɛft ə ðə pɛdlɝz wæɡən, ðoʊ, wɝ blækən aɪɝn wil-ɹɪmz linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə tʃɑɹd wæɡən bɑks, naʊ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ðə bɪɡ ɹaʊn hups ðət hæd hɛld ʌp ðə kænvəs kʌvɝ slæntəd kɹeɪzəli, itʃ əɾ ə dɪfɹən æŋɡəl.

The inn had almost completely escaped the destruction that had taken half the village. A few scorch marks marred its walls, but the red roof tiles glittered in the sunlight as brightly as ever. All that was left of the peddler's wagon, though, were blackened iron wheel-rims leaning against the charred wagon box, now on the ground. The big round hoops that had held up the canvas cover slanted crazily, each at a different angle.

tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn sæt kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɑn ði oʊl faʊndeɪʃən stoʊnz, kɛɹfəli snɪpɪŋ sɪŋʒd ɛdʒəz fɹəm ðə pætʃəz ɑn ɪz kloʊk wɪð ə pɛɹ ə smɔl sɪzɝz. hi sɛt daʊn kloʊk ən sɪzɝz wən ɹænd dʒɹu nɪɹ. wɪθaʊɾ æskɪŋ ɪf ɹænd niɾəd əɹ wɑntəd hɛlp, hi hɑp daʊn ən pɪkt ʌp ðə bæk ə ðə lɪɾɝ.

Thom Merrilin sat cross-legged on the old foundation stones, carefully snipping singed edges from the patches on his cloak with a pair of small scissors. He set down cloak and scissors when Rand drew near. Without asking if Rand needed or wanted help, he hopped down and picked up the back of the litter.

"ɪnsaɪd? ʌv kɔɹs, ʌv kɔɹs. doʊn jə wɝi, bɔɪ. jəɹ wɪzdəm wɪl teɪk kɛɹ ə hɪm. aɪv wɑtʃt əɹ wɝk, sɪns læs naɪt, ən ʃiz ə dɛf tʌtʃ ən ə ʃʊɹ skɪl. ɪt kəd bi ə lɑt wɝs. səm daɪd læs naɪt. nɑt mɛni, pɝhæps, bʌɾ ɛni əɾ ɔl ɑɹ tu mɛni fəɹ mi. oʊl feɪn dʒʌs dɪsəpɪɹd, ən ðæts ðə wɝst ʌv ɔl. tʃɹɑləks wɪl iɾ ɛniθɪŋ. jə ʃəd θæŋk ðə laɪt jəɹ fɑðɝz stɪl hɪɹ, ən əlaɪv fəɹ ðə wɪzdəm tə hil."

"Inside? Of course, of course. Don't you worry, boy. Your Wisdom will take care of him. I've watched her work, since last night, and she has a deft touch and a sure skill. It could be a lot worse. Some died last night. Not many, perhaps, but any at all are too many for me. Old Fain just disappeared, and that's the worst of all. Trollocs will eat anything. You should thank the Light your father's still here, and alive for the Wisdom to heal."
