ðə dɔɹ kloʊz bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ən ɹænd stʊd lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət tæm - lʊkɪŋ ət tæm, bʌt siɪŋ nʌθɪŋ. nɑɾ əntɪl ðət vɛɹi mɪnət hæɾ i ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɛmənz fild wɑz ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm əz mʌtʃ əz i wɑz ə pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. hi ɹilaɪzd ɪt naʊ kəz i nu ðət wɑz wʌɾ i hæd fɛl tɛɹɪŋ lus. hi wɑz əpɑɹt fɹəm ðə vɪlədʒ, naʊ. ðə ʃɛpɝɾ ə ðə naɪt wɑntəd hɪm. ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl - hi wɑz oʊnli ə fɑɹmɝ - bʌt ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd kʌm, ən læn wɑz ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt wʌn θɪŋ. hi kəd nɑt ɹɪsk ðə vɪlədʒ ɑn ðə tʃæns mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ɹɔŋ. hi kəd nɑɾ ivən tɛl ɛniwʌn; ðə kɑplɪnz ɹɪli wəd meɪk tʃɹʌbəl əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðæt. hi hæd tə tʃɹʌst ən ɛɛs sədaɪ.

The door closed behind them, and Rand stood looking down at Tam - looking at Tam, but seeing nothing. Not until that very minute had he realized that Emond's Field was a part of him as much as he was a part of it. He realized it now because he knew that was what he had felt tearing loose. He was apart from the village, now. The Shepherd of the Night wanted him. It was impossible - he was only a farmer - but the Trollocs had come, and Lan was right about one thing. He could not risk the village on the chance Moiraine was wrong. He could not even tell anyone; the Coplins really would make trouble about something like that. He had to trust an Aes Sedai.

"doʊnt weɪk hɪm, naʊ," mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ sɛd, əz ðə meɪɝ ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn ɪz waɪf ən hɪmsɛlf. ðə klɔθ-kʌvɝd tʃɹeɪ ʃi kæɹid ɡeɪv ɔf dɪlɪʃəs, wɔɹm smɛlz. ʃi sɛɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə tʃɛst əɡɛns ðə wɔl, ðən fɝmli muvd ɹænd əweɪ fɹəm ðə bɛd.

"Don't wake him, now," Mistress al'Vere said, as the Mayor shut the door behind his wife and himself. The cloth-covered tray she carried gave off delicious, warm smells. She set it on the chest against the wall, then firmly moved Rand away from the bed.

"mɪstʃɹəs mɔɪɹeɪn toʊl mi wʌɾ i nidz," ʃi sɛd sɔfli, "æn ɪt dʌz nɑɾ ɪnklud jə fɔlɪŋ ɑn tɑp ə hɪm fɹəm ɪɡzɔstʃən. aɪv bɹɔt jə ə baɪt tə it. doʊn lɛɾ ɪt ɡɛt koʊld, naʊ."

"Mistress Moiraine told me what he needs," she said softly, "and it does not include you falling on top of him from exhaustion. I've brought you a bite to eat. Don't let it get cold, now."

"aɪ wɪʃ jə wʊdn kɔl əɹ ðæt," bɹæn sɛd pivɪʃli. "mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ ɪz pɹɑpɝ. ʃi maɪt ɡɛt mæd."

"I wish you wouldn't call her that," Bran said peevishly. "Moiraine Sedai is proper. She might get mad."

mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ ɡeɪv ɪm ə pæɾ ɑn ðə tʃik. "ju dʒʌs liv mi tə wɝi əbaʊt ðæt. ʃi ən aɪ hæɾ ə lɔŋ tɔk. ən kip jəɹ vɔɪs daʊn. ɪf jə weɪk tæm, jəl əv tə ænsɝ tə mi ən mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ." ʃi pʊɾ ən ɛmfəsəs ɑn mɔɪɹeɪnz taɪɾəl ðət meɪd bɹænz ɪnsɪstəns sim fulɪʃ. "ðə tu ʌv jə kip aʊɾ ə maɪ weɪ." wɪð ə fɑn smaɪl fəɹ əɹ hʌzbənd, ʃi tɝn tə ðə bɛɾ ən tæm.

Mistress al'Vere gave him a pat on the cheek. "You just leave me to worry about that. She and I had a long talk. And keep your voice down. If you wake Tam, you'll have to answer to me and Moiraine Sedai." She put an emphasis on Moiraine's title that made Bran's insistence seem foolish. "The two of you keep out of my way." With a fond smile for her husband, she turned to the bed and Tam.

mæstɝ ælvɪɹ ɡeɪv ɹænd ə fɹʌstʃɹeɪɾəd lʊk. "ʃiz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. hæf ðə wɪmən ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ ækt əz ɪf ʃi sɪts ɪn ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl, ən ðə ɹɛst əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ə tʃɹɑlɑk. nɑɾ ə wʌn ə ðɛm simz tə ɹilaɪz juv tə bi kɛɹfəl ɝaʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə mɛn meɪ kip lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ saɪdweɪz, bʌɾ ət lis ðeɪ ɑɹən duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ ðət maɪt pɹəvoʊk hɝ."

Master al'Vere gave Rand a frustrated look. "She's an Aes Sedai. Half the women in the village act as if she sits in the Women's Circle, and the rest as if she were a Trolloc. Not a one of them seems to realize you have to be careful around Aes Sedai. The men may keep looking at her sideways, but at least they aren't doing anything that might provoke her."

kɛɹfəl, ɹænd θɔt. ɪt wɑz nɑt tu leɪt tə stɑɹt biɪŋ kɛɹfəl. "mæstɝ ælvɪɹ," hi sɛd sloʊli, "du jə noʊ haʊ mɛni fɑɹmz wɝ ətækt?"

Careful, Rand thought. It was not too late to start being careful. "Master al'Vere," he said slowly, "do you know how many farms were attacked?"

"oʊnli tu ðəɾ aɪv hɝɾ ə soʊ fɑɹ, ɪnkluɾɪŋ jəɹ pleɪs." ðə meɪɝ pɔzd, fɹaʊnɪŋ, ðən ʃɹʌɡd. "ɪt dʌzn sim ɪnʌf, wɪð wʌt hæpən hɪɹ. aɪ ʃəd bi ɡlæɾ ʌv ɪt, bʌt. . . . wɛl, wɪl pɹɑbli hɪɹ ə mɔɹ bɪfɔɹ ðə deɪ ɪz aʊt."

"Only two that I've heard of so far, including your place." The Mayor paused, frowning, then shrugged. "It doesn't seem enough, with what happened here. I should be glad of it, but. . . . Well, we'll probably hear of more before the day is out."

ɹænd saɪd. noʊ nid tə æsk wɪtʃ fɑɹmz. "hɪɹ ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ, dɪd ðeɪ. . . . aɪ min, wɑz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ tə ʃoʊ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ æftɝ?"

Rand sighed. No need to ask which farms. "Here in the village, did they. . . . I mean, was there anything to show what they were after?"

"æftɝ, bɔɪ? aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðət ðeɪ wɝ æftɝ ɛniθɪŋ, ɪksɛp meɪbi kɪlɪŋ əs ɔl. ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðə weɪ aɪ sɛd. ðə dɑɡz bɑɹkɪŋ, ən mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ ən læn ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu ðə stʃɹits, ðən sʌmbɑɾi ʃaʊɾəd ðət mæstɝ luhənz haʊs ən ðə fɔɹdʒ wɝ ɑn faɪɝ. eɪbəl kɔθənz haʊs flɛɹɾ ʌp - ɑd ðæt; ɪts nɪɹli ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə vɪlədʒ. ɛniweɪ, ðə nɛks θɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ ɔl əmʌŋ ʌs. noʊ, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðeɪ wɝ æftɝ ɛniθɪŋ." hi ɡeɪv ən əbɹʌp bɑɹk ʌv ə læf, ən kʌɾ ɪt ʃɔɹt wɪð ə wɛɹi lʊk əɾ ɪz waɪf. ʃi dɪd nɑt lʊk ɝaʊn fɹəm tæm. "tə tɛl ðə tʃɹuθ," hi wɛn ɑn mɔɹ kwaɪətli, "ðeɪ simd ɔlmoʊst əz kənfjuzd əz wi wɝ. aɪ daʊt ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hɪɹ, əɹ ə wɔɹɾɝ."

"After, boy? I don't know that they were after anything, except maybe killing us all. It was just the way I said. The dogs barking, and Moiraine Sedai and Lan running through the streets, then somebody shouted that Master Luhhan's house and the forge were on fire. Abell Cauthon's house flared up - odd that; it's nearly in the middle of the village. Anyway, the next thing the Trollocs were all among us. No, I don't think they were after anything." He gave an abrupt bark of a laugh, and cut it short with a wary look at his wife. She did not look around from Tam. "To tell the truth," he went on more quietly, "they seemed almost as confused as we were. I doubt they expected to find an Aes Sedai here, or a Warder."

"aɪ səpoʊz nɑt," ɹænd sɛd, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ.

"I suppose not," Rand said, grimacing.

ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn hæd toʊl ðə tʃɹuθ əbaʊt ðæt, ʃi pɹɑbli hæd toʊl ðə tʃɹuθ əbaʊt ðə ɹɛst, tu. fəɹ ə moʊmən i θɔɾ əbaʊɾ æskɪŋ ðə meɪɝz ædvaɪs, bʌt mæstɝ ælvɪɹ ɑbviəsli nu lɪɾəl mɔɹ əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ðən ɛniwʌn ɛls ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ. bɪsaɪdz, hi wɑz ɹɪlʌktən tə tɛl ivən ðə meɪɝ wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn - wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf i wɑz mɔɹ əfɹeɪɾ ə biɪŋ læft əɾ əɹ biɪŋ bɪlivd. hi ɹʌbd ə θʌm əɡɛns ðə hɪlt ə tæmz sɔɹd. hɪz fɑðɝ hæd bɪn aʊɾ ɪndə ðə wɝld; hi mʌs noʊ mɔɹ əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ðən ðə meɪɝ dɪd. bʌɾ ɪf tæm ɹɪli hæd bɪn aʊɾ ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ðən meɪbi wʌɾ i hæd sɛɾ ɪn ðə wɛstwʊd. . . . hi skɹʌbd boʊθ hænz θɹu hɪz hɛɹ, skæɾɝɪŋ ðət laɪn ə θɔt.

If Moiraine had told the truth about that, she probably had told the truth about the rest, too. For a moment he thought about asking the Mayor's advice, but Master al'Vere obviously knew little more about Aes Sedai than anyone else in the village. Besides, he was reluctant to tell even the Mayor what was going on - what Moiraine said was going on. He was not sure if he was more afraid of being laughed at or being believed. He rubbed a thumb against the hilt of Tam's sword. His father had been out into the world; he must know more about Aes Sedai than the Mayor did. But if Tam really had been out of the Two Rivers, then maybe what he had said in the Westwood. . . . He scrubbed both hands through his hair, scattering that line of thought.

"ju nid slip, læd," ðə meɪɝ sɛd.

"You need sleep, lad," the Mayor said.

"jɛs, jə du," mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ æɾəd. "jɔɹ ɔlmoʊs fɔlɪŋ daʊn wɛɹ jə stænd."

"Yes, you do," Mistress al'Vere added. "You're almost falling down where you stand."

ɹænd blɪŋkt əɾ əɹ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. hi hæd nɑɾ ivən ɹilaɪzd ʃi hæd lɛft ɪz fɑðɝ. hi dɪd nid slip; dʒʌs ðə θɔt sɛɾ ɔf ə jɔn.

Rand blinked at her in surprise. He had not even realized she had left his father. He did need sleep; just the thought set off a yawn.

"ju kən teɪk ðə bɛɾ ɪn ðə nɛkst ɹum," ðə meɪɝ sɛd. "ðɛɹz ɔlɹɛɾi ə faɪɝ leɪd."

"You can take the bed in the next room," the Mayor said. "There's already a fire laid."

ɹænd lʊkt əɾ ɪz fɑðɝ; tæm wɑz stɪl dip ɪn slip, ən ðət meɪɾ ɪm jɔn əɡɛn. "aɪd ɹæðɝ steɪ ɪn hɪɹ, ɪf jə doʊn maɪnd. fəɹ wən i weɪks ʌp."

Rand looked at his father; Tam was still deep in sleep, and that made him yawn again. "I'd rather stay in here, if you don't mind. For when he wakes up."

sɪkɹum mæɾɝz wɝ ɪn mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹz pɹɑvəns, ən ðə meɪɝ lɛft ɪt tə hɝ. ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ nɑɾɪŋ. "bʌt jə lɛɾ ɪm weɪk ɑn ɪz oʊn. ɪf jə bɑðɝ ɪz slip. . . ." hi tʃɹaɪd tə seɪ hi wəd də əz ʃi ɔɹɾɝd, bʌt ðə wɝdz ɡɑt tæŋɡəld ɪn jɛɾ ənʌðɝ jɔn. ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd wɪð ə smaɪl. "ju wɪl bi əslip jɝsɛlf ɪn noʊ taɪm əɾ ɔl. ɪf jə mʌst steɪ, kɝl ʌp nɛks tə ðə faɪɝ. ən dʒɹɪŋk ə lɪɾəl ə ðət bif bɹɔθ bɪfɔɹ jə doʊz ɔf."

Sickroom matters were in Mistress al'Vere's province, and the Mayor left it to her. She hesitated only a moment before nodding. "But you let him wake on his own. If you bother his sleep. . . ." He tried to say he would do as she ordered, but the words got tangled in yet another yawn. She shook her head with a smile. "You will be asleep yourself in no time at all. If you must stay, curl up next to the fire. And drink a little of that beef broth before you doze off."

"aɪ wɪl," ɹænd sɛd. hi wʊɾə əɡɹid tə ɛniθɪŋ ðət kɛpt ɪm ɪn ðət ɹum. "æn aɪ woʊnt weɪk hɪm."

"I will," Rand said. He would have agreed to anything that kept him in that room. "And I won't wake him."

"si ðət jə də nɑt," mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ toʊld ɪm fɝmli, bʌt nɑɾ ɪn ən əŋkinli weɪ. "aɪl bɹɪŋ jə ʌp ə pɪloʊ ən səm blæŋkəts."

"See that you do not," Mistress al'Vere told him firmly, but not in an unkindly way. "I'll bring you up a pillow and some blankets."

wən ðə dɔɹ faɪnəli kloʊz bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ɹænd dʒɹæɡd ðə loʊn tʃɛɹ ɪn ðə ɹum oʊvɝ bɪsaɪd ðə bɛɾ ən sæt daʊn wɛɹ i kəd wɑtʃ tæm. ɪt wɑz ɔl vɛɹi wɛl fəɹ mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ tə tɔk əbaʊt slip - hɪz dʒɔz kɹækt əz i staɪfəld ə jɔn - bʌɾ i kəd nɑt slip jɛt. tæm maɪt weɪk əɾ ɛni taɪm, ən meɪbi oʊnli steɪ əweɪk ə ʃɔɹt waɪl. ɹænd hæd tə bi weɪɾɪŋ wən i dɪd.

When the door finally closed behind them, Rand dragged the lone chair in the room over beside the bed and sat down where he could watch Tam. It was all very well for Mistress al'Vere to talk about sleep - his jaws cracked as he stifled a yawn - but he could not sleep yet. Tam might wake at any time, and maybe only stay awake a short while. Rand had to be waiting when he did.

hi ɡɹɪməst ən twɪstəɾ ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ, æbsənli ʃɪftɪŋ ðə sɔɹd hɪlt aʊɾ ə hɪz ɹɪbz. hi stɪl fɛl bækwɝɾ əbaʊt tɛlɪŋ ɛniwʌn wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn hæd sɛd, bʌt ðɪs wɑz tæm, æftɝ ɔl. ðɪs wɑz. . . . wɪθaʊt ɹilaɪzɪŋ ɪɾ i sɛɾ ɪz dʒɔ dətɝmənədli. maɪ fɑðɝ. aɪ kən tɛl maɪ fɑðɝ ɛniθɪŋ.

He grimaced and twisted in the chair, absently shifting the sword hilt out of his ribs. He still felt backward about telling anyone what Moiraine had said, but this was Tam, after all. This was. . . . Without realizing it he set his jaw determinedly. My father. I can tell my father anything.

hi twɪstəɾ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ɪn ðə tʃɛɹ ən pʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ əɡɛns ðə tʃɛɹbæk. tæm wɑz ɪz fɑðɝ, ən noʊbɑdi kəd tɛl ɪm wʌt tə seɪ əɹ nɑt seɪ tə hɪz fɑðɝ. hi dʒʌs hæd tə steɪ əweɪk əntɪl tæm woʊk ʌp. hi dʒʌs hæd tə. . . .

He twisted a little more in the chair and put his head against the chairback. Tam was his father, and nobody could tell him what to say or not say to his father. He just had to stay awake until Tam woke up. He just had to. . . .


tʃæptɝ naɪn


CHAPTER 9

tɛlɪŋz ə ðə wil


Tellings of the Wheel

ɹændz hɑɹt paʊndɪɾ əz i ɹæn, ən i stɛɹɾ ɪn dɪsmeɪ ət ðə bæɹən hɪlz sɝaʊndɪŋ hɪm. ðɪs wɑz nɑt dʒʌst ə pleɪs wɛɹ spɹɪŋ wɑz leɪɾ ɪn kʌmɪŋ; spɹɪŋ hæd nɛvɝ kʌm hɪɹ, ən nɛvɝ wəd kʌm. nʌθɪŋ ɡɹu ɪn ðə koʊl sɔɪl ðət kɹʌntʃt ʌndɝ ɪz buts, nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə bɪɾ ə laɪkən. hi skɹæmbəl pæs boʊldɝz, twaɪs əz tɔl əz i wɑz; dʌs koʊɾəd ðə stoʊn əz ɪf nɛvɝ ə dʒɹɑp ə ɹeɪn hæd tʌtʃt ɪt. ðə sʌn wɑz ə swoʊlən, blʌd-ɹɛd bɔl, mɔɹ faɪɝi ðən ɑn ðə hɑɾəst deɪ ʌv sʌmɝ ən bɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf tə sɪɹ ɪz aɪz, bʌɾ ɪt stʊd stɑɹk əɡɛnst ə lɛɾən kɑlʒɹən ʌv ə skaɪ wɛɹ klaʊdz ə ʃɑɹp blæk ən sɪlvɝ ɹɔɪld ən bɔɪld ɑn ɛvɹi hɝaɪzən. fəɹ ɔl ðə swɝlɪŋ klaʊdz, ðoʊ, noʊ bɹɛθ ə bɹiz stɝɾ əkɹɔs ðə lænd, ən dɪspaɪt ðə sʌlən sʌn ði ɛɹ bɝn koʊld laɪk ðə dɛpθs ʌv wɪntɝ.

Rand's heart pounded as he ran, and he stared in dismay at the barren hills surrounding him. This was not just a place where spring was late in coming; spring had never come here, and never would come. Nothing grew in the cold soil that crunched under his boots, not so much as a bit of lichen. He scrambled past boulders, twice as tall as he was; dust coated the stone as if never a drop of rain had touched it. The sun was a swollen, blood-red ball, more fiery than on the hottest day of summer and bright enough to sear his eyes, but it stood stark against a leaden cauldron of a sky where clouds of sharp black and silver roiled and boiled on every horizon. For all the swirling clouds, though, no breath of breeze stirred across the land, and despite the sullen sun the air burned cold like the depths of winter.

ɹænd lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ɔfən əz i ɹæn, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt si hɪz pɝsuɝz. oʊnli dɛsələt hɪlz ən dʒæɡd blæk maʊntənz, mɛni tɑp baɪ tɔl plumz ə dɑɹk smoʊk ɹaɪzɪŋ tə dʒɔɪn ðə mɪlɪŋ klaʊdz. ɪf i kəd nɑt si hɪz hʌntɝz, ðoʊ, hi kəd hɪɹ ðɛm, haʊlɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm, ɡʌɾɝəl vɔɪsəz ʃaʊɾɪŋ wɪð ðə ɡli ʌv ðə tʃeɪs, haʊlɪŋ wɪð ðə dʒɔɪ ʌv blʌd tə kʌm. tʃɹɑləks. kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ, ən ɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɡɔn.

Rand looked over his shoulder often as he ran, but he could not see his pursuers. Only desolate hills and jagged black mountains, many topped by tall plumes of dark smoke rising to join the milling clouds. If he could not see his hunters, though, he could hear them, howling behind him, guttural voices shouting with the glee of the chase, howling with the joy of blood to come. Trollocs. Coming closer, and his strength was almost gone.

wɪð dɛspɹɪt heɪst i skɹæmbəl tə ðə tɑp ʌv ə naɪf-ɛdʒd ɹɪdʒ, ðən dʒɹɑp tə hɪz niz wɪð ə ɡɹoʊn. bɪloʊ hɪm ə ʃɪɹ ɹɑk wɔl fɛl əweɪ, ə θaʊzənd-fʊt klɪf plʌməɾɪŋ ɪndə ə væs kænjən. stimi mɪsts kʌvɝd ðə kænjən flɔɹ, ðɛɹ θɪk ɡɹeɪ sɝfəs ɹoʊlɪŋ ɪn ɡɹɪm weɪvz, ɹoʊlɪŋ ən bɹeɪkɪŋ əɡɛns ðə klɪf bɪniθ hɪm, bʌt mɔɹ sloʊli ðən ɛni oʊʃən weɪv hæɾ ɛvɝ muvd. pætʃəz ə fɑɡ ɡloʊd ɹɛd fəɹ ən ɪnstən əz ɪf ɡɹeɪt faɪɝz hæd sʌɾənli flɛɹd bɪniθ, ðən daɪd. θʌndɝ ɹʌmbəld ɪn ðə dɛpθs ə ðə væli, ən laɪtnɪŋ kɹækəl θɹu ðə ɡɹeɪ, səmtaɪmz stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ʌp ət ðə skaɪ.

With desperate haste he scrambled to the top of a knife-edged ridge, then dropped to his knees with a groan. Below him a sheer rock wall fell away, a thousand-foot cliff plummeting into a vast canyon. Steamy mists covered the canyon floor, their thick gray surface rolling in grim waves, rolling and breaking against the cliff beneath him, but more slowly than any ocean wave had ever moved. Patches of fog glowed red for an instant as if great fires had suddenly flared beneath, then died. Thunder rumbled in the depths of the valley, and lightning crackled through the gray, sometimes striking up at the sky.

ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə væli ɪtsɛlf ðət sæpt ɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ ən fɪl ði ɛmpti speɪsəz lɛft wɪð hɛlpləsnəs. fɹəm ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə fjʊɹiəs veɪpɝz ə maʊntən θɹʌst ʌpwɝd, ə maʊntən tɔlɝ ðən ɛni hi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst, ə maʊntən əz blæk əz ðə lɔs ʌv ɔl hoʊp. ðət blik stoʊn spaɪɹ, ə dæɡɝ stæbɪŋ ət ðə hɛvənz, wɑz ðə sɔɹs ə hɪz dɛsəleɪʃən. hi hæd nɛvɝ sin ɪt bɪfɔɹ, bʌɾ i nu ɪt. ðə mɛmɹi ʌv ɪt flæʃt əweɪ laɪk kwɪksɪlvɝ wən i tʃɹaɪd tə tʌtʃ ɪt, bʌt ðə mɛmɹi wɑz ðɛɹ. hi nu ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ.

It was not the valley itself that sapped his strength and filled the empty spaces left with helplessness. From the center of the furious vapors a mountain thrust upward, a mountain taller than any he had ever seen in the Mountains of Mist, a mountain as black as the loss of all hope. That bleak stone spire, a dagger stabbing at the heavens, was the source of his desolation. He had never seen it before, but he knew it. The memory of it flashed away like quicksilver when he tried to touch it, but the memory was there. He knew it was there.

ənsin fɪŋɡɝz tʌtʃt hɪm, pʊld əɾ ɪz ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒɹɔ hɪm tə ðə maʊntən. hɪz bɑɾi twɪtʃt, ɹɛɾi tə oʊbeɪ. hɪz ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz stɪfən əz ɪf i θɔɾ i kəd dɪɡ hɪz fɪŋɡɝz ən toʊz ɪndə ðə stoʊn. ɡoʊsli stʃɹɪŋz ɛntwaɪn ɝaʊn ɪz hɑɹt, pʊlɪŋ ɪm kɔlɪŋ ɪm tə ðə spaɪɹ maʊntən. tɪɹz ɹæn daʊn ɪz feɪs, ən i sæɡd tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi fɛlt ɪz wɪl dʒɹeɪnɪŋ əweɪ laɪk wɔɾɝ aʊɾ ʌv ə hoʊl bʌkət. dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ, ən i wəd ɡoʊ wɛɹ i wɑz kɔld. hi wəɾ oʊbeɪ, də əz i wɑz toʊld. əbɹʌpli hi dɪskʌvɝɾ ənʌðɝ ɪmoʊʃən: æŋɡɝ. pʊʃ hɪm, pʊl hɪm, hi wɑz nɑɾ ə ʃip tə bi pɹɑɾɪd ɪndə ə pɛn. ði æŋɡɝ skwizd ɪtsɛlf ɪndə wʌn hɑɹd nɑt, ən i klʌŋ tə ɪɾ əz i wʊɾə klʌŋ tə ə ɹæft ɪn ə flʌd.

Unseen fingers touched him, pulled at his arms and legs, trying to draw him to the mountain. His body twitched, ready to obey. His arms and legs stiffened as if he thought he could dig his fingers and toes into the stone. Ghostly strings entwined around his heart, pulling him calling him to the spire mountain. Tears ran down his face, and he sagged to the ground. He felt his will draining away like water out of a holed bucket. Just a little longer, and he would go where he was called. He would obey, do as he was told. Abruptly he discovered another emotion: anger. Push him, pull him, he was not a sheep to be prodded into a pen. The anger squeezed itself into one hard knot, and he clung to it as he would have clung to a raft in a flood.

sɝv mi, ə vɔɪs wɪspɝɾ ɪn ðə stɪlnəs ə hɪz maɪnd. ə fəmɪljɝ vɔɪs. ɪf i lɪsən hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf i wɑz ʃʊɹ i wəd noʊ ɪt. sɝv mi. hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd tə tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛɾ ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd. sɝv mi! hi ʃʊk ɪz fɪst ət ðə blæk maʊntən. "ðə laɪt kənsum ju, ʃeɪtɑn!"

Serve me, a voice whispered in the stillness of his mind. A familiar voice. If he listened hard enough he was sure he would know it. Serve me. He shook his head to try to get it out of his head. Serve me! He shook his fist at the black mountain. "The Light consume you, Shai'tan!"

əbɹʌpli ðə smɛl ə dɛθ leɪ θɪk ɝaʊn hɪm. ə fɪɡjɝ lumd oʊvɝ hɪm, ɪn ə kloʊk ðə kʌlɝ ə dʒɹaɪd blʌd, ə fɪɡjɝ wɪð ə feɪs. . . . hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə si ðə feɪs ðət lʊk daʊn ət hɪm. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk ə ðət feɪs. ɪt hɝt tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt, tɝn ɪz maɪn tə ɛmbɝz. ə hæn ɹitʃt təwɔɹd hɪm. nɑt kɛɹɪŋ ɪf i fɛl oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ, hi θɹu hɪmsɛlf əweɪ. hi hæd tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ. fɑɹ əweɪ. hi fɛl, fleɪlɪŋ ət ði ɛɹ, wɑntɪŋ tə skɹim, faɪndɪŋ noʊ bɹɛθ fəɹ skɹimɪŋ, noʊ bɹɛθ əɾ ɔl.

Abruptly the smell of death lay thick around him. A figure loomed over him, in a cloak the color of dried blood, a figure with a face. . . . He did not want to see the face that looked down at him. He did not want to think of that face. It hurt to think of it, turned his mind to embers. A hand reached toward him. Not caring if he fell over the edge, he threw himself away. He had to get away. Far away. He fell, flailing at the air, wanting to scream, finding no breath for screaming, no breath at all.

əbɹʌpli hi wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪn ðə bæɹən lænd, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fɔlɪŋ. wɪntɝ-bɹaʊn ɡɹæs flæɾənd ʌndɝ ɪz buts; ɪt sim laɪk flaʊɝz. hi ɔlmoʊs læf tə si skæɾɝd tʃɹiz ən bʊʃəz, lifləs əz ðeɪ wɝ, dɑɾɪŋ ðə dʒɛnli ɹoʊlɪŋ pleɪn ðət naʊ sɝaʊndəd hɪm. ɪn ðə dɪstəns ɹɪɹɾ ə sɪŋɡəl maʊntən, ɪts pik bɹoʊkən ən splɪt, bʌt ðɪs maʊntən bɹɔt noʊ fɪɹ əɹ dɪspɛɹ. ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə maʊntən, ðoʊ ɑdli aʊɾ ə pleɪs ðɛɹ, wɪð noʊ ʌðɝ ɪn saɪt.

Abruptly he was no longer in the barren land, no longer falling. Winter-brown grass flattened under his boots; it seemed like flowers. He almost laughed to see scattered trees and bushes, leafless as they were, dotting the gently rolling plain that now surrounded him. In the distance reared a single mountain, its peak broken and split, but this mountain brought no fear or despair. It was just a mountain, though oddly out of place there, with no other in sight.

ə bɹɔd ɹɪvɝ floʊd baɪ ðə maʊntən, ən ɑn ən aɪlən ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðət ɹɪvɝ wɑz ə sɪɾi sətʃ əz maɪt lɪv ɪn ə ɡlimənz teɪl, ə sɪɾi sɝaʊndəd baɪ haɪ wɔlz ɡlimɪŋ waɪɾ ən sɪlvɝ bɪniθ ðə wɔɹm sʌn. wɪð mɪŋɡəld ɹɪlif ən dʒɔɪ hi stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə wɔlz, fəɹ ðə seɪfti ən sɝɛnəɾi hi sʌmhaʊ nu hi wəd faɪn bɪhaɪn ðɛm.

A broad river flowed by the mountain, and on an island in the middle of that river was a city such as might live in a gleeman's tale, a city surrounded by high walls gleaming white and silver beneath the warm sun. With mingled relief and joy he started for the walls, for the safety and serenity he somehow knew he would find behind them.

əz i keɪm kloʊsɝ i meɪɾ aʊt sɔɹɪŋ taʊɝz, mɛni dʒɔɪn baɪ wʌnʒɹəs wɔkweɪz ðət spæn ði oʊpən ɛɹ. haɪ bɹɪdʒəz ɑɹtʃt fɹəm boʊθ bæŋks ə ðə ɹɪvɝ tə ði aɪlən sɪɾi. ivən əɾ ə dɪstəns i kəd si leɪsi stoʊnwɝk ɑn ðoʊz spænz, simɪŋli tu dɛləkət tə wɪθstæn ðə swɪft wɔɾɝz ðət ɹʌʃt bɪniθ ðɛm. bɪɑn ðoʊz bɹɪdʒəz leɪ seɪfti. sæŋktʃuɛɹi.

As he came closer he made out soaring towers, many joined by wondrous walkways that spanned the open air. High bridges arched from both banks of the river to the island city. Even at a distance he could see lacy stonework on those spans, seemingly too delicate to withstand the swift waters that rushed beneath them. Beyond those bridges lay safety. Sanctuary.

ʌv ə sʌɾən ə tʃɪl ɹæn əlɔŋ ɪz boʊnz; ən aɪsi klæmənəs sɛɾəld ɑn ɪz skɪn, ən ði ɛɹ ɝaʊn ɪm tɝn fɛɾəd ən dæŋk. wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ bæk i ɹæn, ɹæn fɹəm ðə pɝsuɝ huz fɹizɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz bɹʌʃt ɪz bæk ən tʌɡd əɾ ɪz kloʊk, ɹæn fɹəm ðə laɪt-iɾɪŋ fɪɡjɝ wɪð ðə feɪs ðæt. . . . hi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə feɪs, ɪksɛpt əz tɛɹɝ. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə feɪs. hi ɹæn, ən ðə ɡɹaʊn pæs bɪniθ ɪz fit, ɹoʊlɪŋ hɪlz ən flæt pleɪn . . . ən i wɑntəd tə haʊl laɪk ə dɔɡ ɡɔn mæd. ðə sɪɾi wɑz ɹɪsiɾɪŋ bɪfɔɹ hɪm. ðə hɑɹɾɝ i ɹæn, ðə fɝðɝ əweɪ dʒɹɪftəd ðə waɪt ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz ən heɪvən. ðeɪ ɡɹu smɔlɝ, ən smɔlɝ, əntɪl oʊnli ə peɪl spɛk ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən. ðə koʊl hæn ə hɪz pɝsuɝ klʌtʃt əɾ ɪz kɑlɝ. ɪf ðoʊz fɪŋɡɝz tʌtʃt ɪm i nu hi wəd ɡoʊ mæd. əɹ wɝs. mʌtʃ wɝs. ivən əz ðət ʃʊɹəɾi keɪm tə hɪm i tʃɹɪpt ən fɛl . . .

Of a sudden a chill ran along his bones; an icy clamminess settled on his skin, and the air around him turned fetid and dank. Without looking back he ran, ran from the pursuer whose freezing fingers brushed his back and tugged at his cloak, ran from the light-eating figure with the face that. . . . He could not remember the face, except as terror. He did not want to remember the face. He ran, and the ground passed beneath his feet, rolling hills and flat plain . . . and he wanted to howl like a dog gone mad. The city was receding before him. The harder he ran, the further away drifted the white shining walls and haven. They grew smaller, and smaller, until only a pale speck remained on the horizon. The cold hand of his pursuer clutched at his collar. If those fingers touched him he knew he would go mad. Or worse. Much worse. Even as that surety came to him he tripped and fell . . .

"nuuu!" hi skɹimd.

"Noooo!" he screamed.

. . . ən ɡɹʌntɪɾ əz peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz smæk ðə bɹɛθ aʊɾ ə hɪm. wʌndɝɪŋli hi ɡɑt tə hɪz fit. hi stʊɾ ɑn ði əpɹoʊtʃɪz tə wʌn ə ðə mɑɹvələs bɹɪdʒəz i hæd sin ɹɪɹɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪvɝ. smaɪlɪŋ pipəl wɔk baɪ ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm, pipəl dʒɹɛst ɪn soʊ mɛni kʌlɝz ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ʌv ə fild ʌv waɪldflaʊɹz. səm ə ðɛm spoʊk tə hɪm, bʌɾ i kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd, ðoʊ ðə wɝdz saʊndəɾ əz ɪf i ʃʊd. bʌt ðə feɪsəz wɝ fɹɛnli, ən ðə pipəl dʒɛstʃɝɾ ɪm ɔnwɝd, oʊvɝ ðə bɹɪdʒ wɪð ɪts ɪntʃɹəkət stoʊnwɝk, ɔnwɝd təwɔɹd ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ, sɪlvɝ-stʃɹikt wɔlz ən ðə taʊɝz bɪɑnd. təwɔɹd ðə seɪfti hi nu weɪɾəd ðɛɹ.

. . . and grunted as paving stones smacked the breath out of him. Wonderingly he got to his feet. He stood on the approaches to one of the marvelous bridges he had seen rearing over the river. Smiling people walked by on either side of him, people dressed in so many colors they made him think of a field of wildflowers. Some of them spoke to him, but he could not understand, though the words sounded as if he should. But the faces were friendly, and the people gestured him onward, over the bridge with its intricate stonework, onward toward the shining, silver-streaked walls and the towers beyond. Toward the safety he knew waited there.

hi dʒɔɪn ðə θɹɔŋ stʃɹimɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə bɹɪdʒ ən ɪndə ðə sɪɾi θɹu mæsɪv ɡeɪts sɛɾ ɪn tɔl, pɹɪstin wɔlz. wɪðɪn wɑz ə wʌndɝlænd wɛɹ ðə minəst stʃɹʌktʃɝ simd ə pæləs. ɪt wɑz əz ðoʊ ðə bɪldɝz hæd bɪn toʊl tə teɪk stoʊn ən bɹɪk ən taɪl ən kɹieɪt bjuɾi tə teɪk ðə bɹɛθ ə mɔɹɾəl mɛn. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bɪldɪŋ, noʊ mɑnjəmən ðət dɪd nɑt meɪk ɪm stɛɹ wɪð ɡɑəlɪŋ aɪz. mjuzɪk dʒɹɪftəd daʊn ðə stʃɹits, ə hʌnʒɹəd dɪfɹən sɔŋz, bʌɾ ɔl blɛndɪŋ wɪð ðə klæmɝ ə ðə kɹaʊdz tə meɪk wʌn ɡɹænd, dʒɔɪəs hɑɹməni. ðə sɛns ə swit pɝfjumz ən ʃɑɹp spaɪsəz, ʌv wʌnʒɹəs fudz ən mɪɹiəd flaʊɝz, ɔl floʊɾəd ɪn ði ɛɹ, əz ɪf ɛvɹi ɡʊd smɛl ɪn ðə wɝld wɝ ɡæðɝd ðɛɹ.

He joined the throng streaming across the bridge and into the city through massive gates set in tall, pristine walls. Within was a wonderland where the meanest structure seemed a palace. It was as though the builders had been told to take stone and brick and tile and create beauty to take the breath of mortal men. There was no building, no monument that did not make him stare with goggling eyes. Music drifted down the streets, a hundred different songs, but all blending with the clamor of the crowds to make one grand, joyous harmony. The scents of sweet perfumes and sharp spices, of wondrous foods and myriad flowers, all floated in the air, as if every good smell in the world were gathered there.

ðə stʃɹit baɪ wɪtʃ i ɛntɝd ðə sɪɾi, bɹɔɾ ən peɪvd wɪð smuð, ɡɹeɪ stoʊn, stʃɹɛtʃt stʃɹeɪt bɪfɔɹ ɪm təwɔɹd ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə sɪɾi. əɾ ɪts ɛn lumd ə taʊɝ lɑɹdʒɝ ən tɔlɝ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ə taʊɝ əz waɪɾ əz fɹɛʃ-fɔlən snoʊ. ðət taʊɝ wɑz wɛɹ seɪfti leɪ, ən ðə nɑlədʒ i sɔt. bʌt ðə sɪɾi wɑz sətʃ əz i hæd nɛvɝ dʒɹimd ə siɪŋ. ʃʊɹli ɪt wəd nɑt mæɾɝ ɪf i dɪleɪd dʒʌst ə ʃɔɹt taɪm ɪn ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðə taʊɝ? hi tɝn əsaɪɾ ɑntu ə nɛɹoʊɝ stʃɹit, wɛɹ dʒʌɡəlɝz stʃɹoʊld əmʌŋ hɔkɝz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ fɹuts.

The street by which he entered the city, broad and paved with smooth, gray stone, stretched straight before him toward the center of the city. At its end loomed a tower larger and taller than any other in the city, a tower as white as fresh-fallen snow. That tower was where safety lay, and the knowledge he sought. But the city was such as he had never dreamed of seeing. Surely it would not matter if he delayed just a short time in going to the tower? He turned aside onto a narrower street, where jugglers strolled among hawkers of strange fruits.

əhɛɾ ə hɪm daʊn ðə stʃɹit wɑz ə snoʊ-waɪt taʊɝ. ðə seɪm taʊɝ. ɪn dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl waɪl, hi θɔt, ən ɹaʊndəɾ ənʌðɝ kɔɹnɝ. ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðɪs stʃɹit, tu, leɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝ. stʌbɝnli hi tɝn ənʌðɝ kɔɹnɝ, ən ənʌðɝ, ən itʃ taɪm ði æləbæstɝ taʊɝ mɛɾ ɪz aɪz. hi spʌn tə ɹʌn əweɪ fɹəm ɪt . . . ən skɪɾəd tə ə hɔlt. bɪfɔɹ hɪm, ðə waɪt taʊɝ. hi wɑz əfɹeɪd tə lʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, əfɹeɪɾ ɪt wəd bi ðɛɹ, tu.

Ahead of him down the street was a snow-white tower. The same tower. In just a little while, he thought, and rounded another corner. At the far end of this street, too, lay the white tower. Stubbornly he turned another corner, and another, and each time the alabaster tower met his eyes. He spun to run away from it . . . and skidded to a halt. Before him, the white tower. He was afraid to look over his shoulder, afraid it would be there, too.

ðə feɪsəz ɝaʊn ɪm wɝ stɪl fɹɛnli, bʌt ʃæɾɝd hoʊp fɪld əm naʊ, hoʊp i hæd bɹoʊkən. stɪl ðə pipəl dʒɛstʃɝɾ ɪm fɔɹwɝd, pliɾɪŋ dʒɛstʃɝz. təwɔɹd ðə taʊɝ. ðɛɹ aɪz ʃoʊn wɪð dɛspɹɪt nid, ən oʊnli hi kəd fʊlfɪl ɪt, oʊnli hi kəd seɪv ðɛm.

The faces around him were still friendly, but shattered hope filled them now, hope he had broken. Still the people gestured him forward, pleading gestures. Toward the tower. Their eyes shone with desperate need, and only he could fulfill it, only he could save them.

vɛɹi wɛl, hi θɔt. ðə taʊɝ wɑz, æftɝ ɔl, wɛɹ i wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ.

Very well, he thought. The tower was, after all, where he wanted to go.

ivən əz i tʊk ɪz fɝst stɛp fɔɹwɝd dɪsəpɔɪnmənt feɪɾəd fɹəm ðoʊz əbaʊt hɪm, ən smaɪlz ɹɛðd ɛvɹi feɪs. ðeɪ muvd wɪð hɪm, ən smɔl tʃɪlʒɹən stʃɹuɾ ɪz pæθ wɪð flaʊɝ pɛɾəlz. hi lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ɪn kənfjuʒən, wʌndɝɪŋ u ðə flaʊɝz wɝ mɛn fɔɹ, bʌt bɪhaɪn ɪm wɝ oʊnli mɔɹ smaɪlɪŋ pipəl dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ ɪm ɑn. ðeɪ mʌs bi fəɹ mi, hi θɔt, ən wʌndɝd waɪ ðət sʌɾənli dɪd nɑt sim stʃɹeɪnʒ əɾ ɔl. bʌt wʌndɝmən læstəɾ oʊnli ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ mɛltɪŋ əweɪ; ɔl wɑz əz ɪt ʃəd bi.

Even as he took his first step forward disappointment faded from those about him, and smiles wreathed every face. They moved with him, and small children strewed his path with flower petals. He looked over his shoulder in confusion, wondering who the flowers were meant for, but behind him were only more smiling people gesturing him on. They must be for me, he thought, and wondered why that suddenly did not seem strange at all. But wonderment lasted only a moment before melting away; all was as it should be.

fɝst wʌn, ðən ənʌðɝ ə ðə pipəl bɪɡæn tə sɪŋ, əntɪl ɛvɹi vɔɪs wɑz lɪftəɾ ɪn ə ɡlɔɹiəs ænθəm. hi stɪl kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðə wɝdz, bʌɾ ə dʌzən ɪntɝwivɪŋ hɑɹməniz ʃaʊɾəd dʒɔɪ ən sælveɪʃən. mjuzɪʃənz keɪpɝd θɹu ði ɑn-floʊɪŋ kɹaʊd, æɾɪŋ fluts ən hɑɹps ən dʒɹʌmz ɪn ə dʌzən saɪzəz tə ðə hɪm, ən ɔl ðə sɔŋz i hæd hɝd bɪfɔɹ blɛndəɾ ɪn wɪθaʊt sim. ɡɝlz dænst ɝaʊn hɪm, leɪɪŋ ɡɑɹlænz ə swit-smɛlɪŋ blɑsəmz əkɹɔs ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, twaɪnɪŋ əm əbaʊɾ ɪz nɛk. ðeɪ smaɪld ət hɪm, ðɛɹ dɪlaɪt ɡɹoʊɪŋ wɪð ɛvɹi stɛp i tʊk. hi kəd nɑt hɛlp bʌt smaɪl bæk. hɪz fiɾ ɪtʃt tə dʒɔɪn ɪn ðɛɹ dæns, ən ivən əz i θɔɾ ʌv ɪɾ i wɑz dænsɪŋ, hɪz stɛps fɪɾɪŋ əz ɪf i hæd noʊn ɪɾ ɔl fɹəm bɝθ. hi θɹu bæk ɪz hɛɾ ən læft; hɪz fit wɝ laɪɾɝ ðən ðeɪ hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn, dænsɪŋ wɪð. . . . hi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə neɪm, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt sim ɪmpɔɹɾənt.

First one, then another of the people began to sing, until every voice was lifted in a glorious anthem. He still could not understand the words, but a dozen interweaving harmonies shouted joy and salvation. Musicians capered through the on-flowing crowd, adding flutes and harps and drums in a dozen sizes to the hymn, and all the songs he had heard before blended in without seam. Girls danced around him, laying garlands of sweet-smelling blossoms across his shoulders, twining them about his neck. They smiled at him, their delight growing with every step he took. He could not help but smile back. His feet itched to join in their dance, and even as he thought of it he was dancing, his steps fitting as if he had known it all from birth. He threw back his head and laughed; his feet were lighter than they had ever been, dancing with. . . . He could not remember the name, but it did not seem important.

ɪts jəɹ dɛstəni, ə vɔɪs wɪspɝɾ ɪn ɪz hɛd, ən ðə wɪspɝ wɑz ə θɹɛɾ ɪn ðə piən.

It is your destiny, a voice whispered in his head, and the whisper was a thread in the paean.

kæɹiɪŋ ɪm laɪk ə twɪɡ ɑn ðə kɹɛst ʌv ə weɪv, ðə kɹaʊd floʊɾ ɪndə ə hjudʒ skwɛɹ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə sɪɾi, ən fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm i sɔ ðət ðə waɪt taʊɝ ɹoʊz fɹəm ə ɡɹeɪt pæləs ə peɪl mɑɹbəl, skʌlptɪd ɹæðɝ ðən bɪlt, kɝvɪŋ wɔlz ən swɛlɪŋ doʊmz ən dɛləkət spaɪɹz fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə skaɪ. ðə hoʊl ʌv ɪt meɪɾ ɪm ɡæsp ɪn ɑ. bɹɔd stɛɹz ə pɹɪstin stoʊn lɛɾ ʌp fɹəm ðə skwɛɹ, ən ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðoʊz stɛɹz ðə pipəl hɔltəd, bʌt ðɛɹ sɔŋ ɹoʊz ɛvɝ haɪɝ. ðə swɛlɪŋ vɔɪsəz buiɾ ɪz fit. jəɹ dɛstəni, ðə vɔɪs wɪspɝd, ɪnsɪstənt naʊ, iɡɝ.

Carrying him like a twig on the crest of a wave, the crowd flowed into a huge square in the middle of the city, and for the first time he saw that the white tower rose from a great palace of pale marble, sculpted rather than built, curving walls and swelling domes and delicate spires fingering the sky. The whole of it made him gasp in awe. Broad stairs of pristine stone led up from the square, and at the foot of those stairs the people halted, but their song rose ever higher. The swelling voices buoyed his feet. Your destiny, the voice whispered, insistent now, eager.

hi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ dænst, bʌt niðɝ dɪɾ i stɑp. hi maʊntəd ðə stɛɹz wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən. ðɪs wɑz wɛɹ i bɪlɔŋd.

He no longer danced, but neither did he stop. He mounted the stairs without hesitation. This was where he belonged.

skɹɑlwɝk kʌvɝd ðə mæsɪv dɔɹz ət ðə tɑp ə ðə stɛɹz, kɑɹvɪŋz soʊ ɪntʃɹəkəɾ ən dɛləkət ðəɾ i kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən ə naɪf bleɪd faɪn ɪnʌf tə fɪt. ðə pɔɹɾəlz swʌŋ oʊpən, ən i wɛn ɪn. ðeɪ kloʊz bɪhaɪn ɪm wɪð ən ɛkoʊɪŋ kɹæʃ laɪk θʌndɝ.

Scrollwork covered the massive doors at the top of the stairs, carvings so intricate and delicate that he could not imagine a knife blade fine enough to fit. The portals swung open, and he went in. They closed behind him with an echoing crash like thunder.

"wi hæv bɪn weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ju," ðə mɹdʒɹɑl hɪst.

"We have been waiting for you," the Myrddraal hissed.

ɹænd sæt boʊlt əpɹaɪt, ɡæspɪŋ fəɹ bɹɛθ ən ʃɪvɝɪŋ, stɛɹɪŋ. tæm wɑz stɪl əslip ɑn ðə bɛd. sloʊli hɪz bɹiðɪŋ sloʊd. hæf-kənsum lɔɡz bleɪzd ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪs wɪð ə ɡʊd bɛɾ ə koʊlz bɪlt ʌp ɝaʊn ðə faɪɝ-aɪɝnz; sʌmwʌn hæd bɪn ðəɹ tə tɛn ɪt waɪl i slɛpt. ə blæŋkət leɪ əɾ ɪz fit, wɛɹ ɪt hæd fɔlən wən i woʊk. ðə meɪkʃɪf lɪɾɝ wɑz ɡɔn, tu, ən ɪz ən tæmz kloʊks hæd bɪn hʌŋ baɪ ðə dɔɹ.

Rand sat bolt upright, gasping for breath and shivering, staring. Tam was still asleep on the bed. Slowly his breathing slowed. Half-consumed logs blazed in the fireplace with a good bed of coals built up around the fire-irons; someone had been there to tend it while he slept. A blanket lay at his feet, where it had fallen when he woke. The makeshift litter was gone, too, and his and Tam's cloaks had been hung by the door.

hi waɪp koʊl swɛt fɹəm ɪz feɪs wɪð ə hæn ðət wɑz nʌn tu stɛɾi ən wʌndɝɾ ɪf neɪmɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪn ə dʒɹim bɹɔɾ ɪz ətɛnʃən ðə seɪm weɪ ðət neɪmɪŋ ɪm əlaʊd dɪd.

He wiped cold sweat from his face with a hand that was none too steady and wondered if naming the Dark One in a dream brought his attention the same way that naming him aloud did.

twaɪlaɪt dɑɹkən ðə wɪndoʊ; ðə mun wɑz wɛl ʌp, ɹaʊn ən fæt, ən ivnɪŋ stɑɹz spɑɹkəld əbʌv ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst. hi hæd slɛp ðə deɪ əweɪ. hi ɹʌbd ə sɔɹ spɑɾ ɑn ɪz saɪd. əpɛɹənli hi hæd slɛpt wɪð ðə sɔɹd hɪl dʒæbɪŋ ɪm ɪn ðə ɹɪbz. bɪtwin ðəɾ ən ən ɛmpti stʌmək ən ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ, ɪt wɑz noʊ wʌndɝ i hæd hæd naɪtmɛɹz.

Twilight darkened the window; the moon was well up, round and fat, and evening stars sparkled above the Mountains of Mist. He had slept the day away. He rubbed a sore spot on his side. Apparently he had slept with the sword hilt jabbing him in the ribs. Between that and an empty stomach and the night before, it was no wonder he had had nightmares.

hɪz bɛli ɹʌmbəld, ən i ɡɑɾ ʌp stɪfli ən meɪɾ ɪz weɪ tə ðə teɪbəl wɛɹ mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ hæd lɛf ðə tʃɹeɪ. hi twɪtʃt əsaɪd ðə waɪt næpkɪn. dɪspaɪt ðə taɪm i hæd slɛpt, ðə bif bɹɔθ wɑz stɪl wɔɹm, ən soʊ wɑz ðə kɹʌsti bɹɛd. mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹz hænd wɑz pleɪn; ðə tʃɹeɪ hæd bɪn ɹipleɪst. wʌns ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd jə niɾəd ə hɑt mil, ʃi dɪd nɑt ɡɪv ʌp tɪl ɪt wɑz ɪnsaɪd ju.

His belly rumbled, and he got up stiffly and made his way to the table where Mistress al'Vere had left the tray. He twitched aside the white napkin. Despite the time he had slept, the beef broth was still warm, and so was the crusty bread. Mistress al'Vere's hand was plain; the tray had been replaced. Once she decided you needed a hot meal, she did not give up till it was inside you.

hi ɡʌlp daʊn səm bɹɔθ, ən ɪt wɑz ɔl i kəd də tə pʊt səm miɾ ən tʃiz bɪtwin tu pisəz ə bɹɛd bɪfɔɹ stʌfɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn ɪz maʊθ. teɪkɪŋ bɪɡ baɪts, hi wɛn bæk tə ðə bɛd.

He gulped down some broth, and it was all he could do to put some meat and cheese between two pieces of bread before stuffing it in his mouth. Taking big bites, he went back to the bed.

mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ hæɾ əpɛɹənli sin tə tæm, əz wɛl. tæm hæd bɪn ənʒɹəst, hɪz kloʊðz naʊ klin ən nitli foʊldəɾ ɑn ðə bɛdsaɪd teɪbəl, ən ə blæŋkət wɑz dʒɹɔn ʌp ʌndɝ ɪz tʃɪn. wən ɹænd tʌtʃt ɪz fɑðɝz fɔɹhɛd, tæm oʊpən ɪz aɪz.

Mistress al'Vere had apparently seen to Tam, as well. Tam had been undressed, his clothes now clean and neatly folded on the bedside table, and a blanket was drawn up under his chin. When Rand touched his father's forehead, Tam opened his eyes.

"ðɛɹ jə ɑɹ, bɔɪ. mɛɹɪn sɛd jə wɝ hɪɹ, bʌɾ aɪ kʊdn ivən sɪɾ ʌp tə si. ʃi sɛd jə wɝ tu taɪɝd fəɹ əɹ tə weɪk dʒʌst soʊ aɪ kəd lʊk ət ju. ivən bɹæn kænt ɡɛɾ ɝaʊn əɹ wən ʃiz əɹ maɪn sɛt."

"There you are, boy. Marin said you were here, but I couldn't even sit up to see. She said you were too tired for her to wake just so I could look at you. Even Bran can't get around her when she has her mind set."

tæmz vɔɪs wɑz wik, bʌɾ ɪz ɡeɪz wɑz klɪɹ ən stɛɾi. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz ɹaɪt, ɹænd θɔt. wɪð ɹɛst i wəd bi əz ɡʊɾ əz ɛvɝ.

Tam's voice was weak, but his gaze was clear and steady. The Aes Sedai was right, Rand thought. With rest he would be as good as ever.

"kæn aɪ ɡɛt jə sʌmθɪŋ tə it? mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ lɛft ə tʃɹeɪ."

"Can I get you something to eat? Mistress al'Vere left a tray."

"ʃi fɛd mi ɔlɹɛɾi . . . ɪf jə kən kɔl ɪt ðæt. wʊdn lemi hæv ɛniθɪŋ bʌt bɹɔθ. haʊ kən ə mæn əvɔɪd bæd dʒɹimz wɪð nʌθɪŋ bʌt bɹɔθ ɪn hɪz. . . ." tæm fʌmbəld ə hæn fɹəm ʌndɝ ðə kʌvɝ ən tʌtʃt ðə sɔɹɾ ət ɹændz weɪst. "ðɛn ɪt wɑzn ə dʒɹim. wən mɛɹɪn toʊl mi aɪ wɑz sɪk, aɪ θɔɾ aɪ hæd bɪn. . . . bʌt jəɹ ɔl ɹaɪt. ðəɾ ɪz ɔl ðət mæɾɝz. wʌɾ ə ðə fɑɹm?"

"She fed me already . . . if you can call it that. Wouldn't let me have anything but broth. How can a man avoid bad dreams with nothing but broth in his. . . ." Tam fumbled a hand from under the cover and touched the sword at Rand's waist. "Then it wasn't a dream. When Marin told me I was sick, I thought I had been. . . . But you're all right. That is all that matters. What of the farm?"

ɹænd tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "ðə tʃɹɑləks kɪl ðə ʃip. aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ tʊk ðə kaʊ, tu, ən ðə haʊs nidz ə ɡʊd klinɪŋ." hi mænədʒd ə wik smaɪl. "wi wɝ lʌkiɝ ðən sʌm. ðeɪ bɝn hæf ðə vɪlədʒ."

Rand took a deep breath. "The Trollocs killed the sheep. I think they took the cow, too, and the house needs a good cleaning." He managed a weak smile. "We were luckier than some. They burned half the village."

hi toʊl tæm ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət hæd hæpənd, əɹ ət lis moʊst ʌv ɪt. tæm lɪsən kloʊsli, ən æskt ʃɑɹp kwɛstʃənz, soʊ hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf hævɪŋ tə tɛl əbaʊt ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə ðə fɑɹmhaʊs fɹəm ðə wʊdz, ən ðət bɹɔɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk i hæd kɪld. hi hæd tə tɛl haʊ nɪneɪiv hæd sɛd tæm wɑz daɪɪŋ tə ɪkspleɪn waɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd tɛndəɾ ɪm ɪnstɛɾ ə ðə wɪzdəm. tæmz aɪz waɪɾənd ət ðæt, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ɛmənz fild. bʌt ɹænd kəd si noʊ nid tə ɡoʊ oʊvɝ ɛvɹi stɛp ə ðə dʒɝni fɹəm ðə fɑɹm, əɹ ɪz fɪɹz, əɹ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl ɑn ðə ɹoʊd. sɝɾənli nɑɾ ɪz naɪtmɛɹz əz i slɛp baɪ ðə bɛd. ɪspɛʃli hi sɔ noʊ ɹizən tə mɛnʃən tæmz ɹæmbəlɪŋz ʌndɝ ðə fivɝ. nɑt jɛt. mɔɪɹeɪnz stɔɹi, ðoʊ: ðəɹ wɑz noʊ əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðæt.

He told Tam everything that had happened, or at least most of it. Tam listened closely, and asked sharp questions, so he found himself having to tell about returning to the farmhouse from the woods, and that brought in the Trolloc he had killed. He had to tell how Nynaeve had said Tam was dying to explain why the Aes Sedai had tended him instead of the Wisdom. Tam's eyes widened at that, an Aes Sedai in Emond's Field. But Rand could see no need to go over every step of the journey from the farm, or his fears, or the Myrddraal on the road. Certainly not his nightmares as he slept by the bed. Especially he saw no reason to mention Tam's ramblings under the fever. Not yet. Moiraine's story, though: there was no avoiding that.

"naʊ ðæts ə teɪl tə meɪk ə ɡlimən pɹaʊd," tæm mʌɾɝd wən i wɑz dʌn. "wʌt wəd tʃɹɑləks wɑnt wɪð jə bɔɪz? əɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn, laɪt hɛlp ʌs?"

"Now that's a tale to make a gleeman proud," Tam muttered when he was done. "What would Trollocs want with you boys? Or the Dark One, Light help us?"

"ju θɪŋk ʃi wɑz laɪɪŋ? mæstɝ ælvɪɹ sɛd ʃi wɑz tɛlɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ əbaʊɾ oʊnli tu fɑɹmz biɪŋ ətækt. ən əbaʊt mæstɝ luhənz haʊs, ən mæstɝ kɔθənz."

"You think she was lying? Master al'Vere said she was telling the truth about only two farms being attacked. And about Master Luhhan's house, and Master Cauthon's."

fəɹ ə moʊmən tæm leɪ saɪlən bɪfɔɹ seɪɪŋ, "tɛl mi wʌt ʃi sɛd. hɝ ɪɡzækt wɝdz, maɪnd, dʒʌst əz ʃi sɛd ðɛm."

For a moment Tam lay silent before saying, "Tell me what she said. Her exact words, mind, just as she said them."

ɹænd stʃɹʌɡəld. hu ɛvɝ ɹɪmɛmbɝd ði ɪɡzækt wɝdz ðeɪ hɝd? hi tʃuɾ əɾ ɪz lɪp ən skɹætʃt ɪz hɛd, ən bɪt baɪ bɪɾ i bɹɔɾ ɪɾ aʊt, əz nɪɹli əz i kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ. "aɪ kæn θɪŋk ʌv ɛniθɪŋ ɛls," hi fɪnɪʃt. "sʌm ʌv ɪɾ aɪm nɑt tu ʃʊɹ ʃi dɪdn seɪ ə lɪɾəl dɪfɹənli, bʌɾ ɪts kloʊs, ɛniweɪ."

Rand struggled. Who ever remembered the exact words they heard? He chewed at his lip and scratched his head, and bit by bit he brought it out, as nearly as he could remember. "I can't think of anything else," he finished. "Some of it I'm not too sure she didn't say a little differently, but it's close, anyway."

"ɪts ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf. ɪts tə bi, dʌzn ɪt? jə si, læd, ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ tʃɹɪksəm. ðeɪ doʊn laɪ, nɑt ɹaɪɾ aʊt, bʌt ðə tʃɹuθ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ tɛlz jə ɪz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz ðə tʃɹuθ jə θɪŋk ɪɾ ɪz. jə teɪk kɛɹ ɝaʊn hɝ."

"It's good enough. It has to be, doesn't it? You see, lad, Aes Sedai are tricksome. They don't lie, not right out, but the truth an Aes Sedai tells you is not always the truth you think it is. You take care around her."

"aɪv hɝd ðə stɔɹiz," ɹænd ɹitɔɹɾɪd. "aɪm nɑɾ ə tʃaɪld."

"I've heard the stories," Rand retorted. "I'm not a child."

"soʊ jəɹ nɑt, soʊ jəɹ nɑt." tæm saɪd hɛvəli, ðən ʃɹʌɡd ɪn ənɔɪəns. "aɪ ʃəd bi ɡoʊɪŋ əlɔŋ wɪð ju, dʒʌs ðə seɪm. ðə wɝld aʊtsaɪd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɪz nʌθɪŋ laɪk ɛmənz fild."

"So you're not, so you're not." Tam sighed heavily, then shrugged in annoyance. "I should be going along with you, just the same. The world outside the Two Rivers is nothing like Emond's Field."

ðət wɑz ən oʊpənɪŋ tə æsk əbaʊt tæm ɡoʊɪŋ aʊtsaɪɾ ən ɔl ðə ɹɛst ʌv ɪt, bʌt ɹænd dɪd nɑt teɪk ɪt. hɪz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən, ɪnstɛd. "dʒʌs laɪk ðæt? aɪ θɔt jə wəd tʃɹaɪ tə tɔk mi aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. aɪ θɔt juɾ əv ə hʌnʒɹəd ɹizənz aɪ ʃəd nɑt ɡoʊ." hi ɹilaɪzd i hæd bɪn hoʊpɪŋ tæm wəɾ əv ə hʌnʒɹəd ɹizənz, ən ɡʊd wʌnz.

That was an opening to ask about Tam going outside and all the rest of it, but Rand did not take it. His mouth fell open, instead. "Just like that? I thought you would try to talk me out of it. I thought you'd have a hundred reasons I should not go." He realized he had been hoping Tam would have a hundred reasons, and good ones.

"meɪbi nɑɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd," tæm sɛd wɪð ə snɔɹt, "bʌɾ ə fju dɪd kʌm tə maɪnd. oʊnli ðeɪ doʊn kaʊn fəɹ mʌtʃ. ɪf tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ æftɝ ju, jəl bi seɪfɝ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn ðən jə kəɾ ɛvɝ bi hɪɹ. dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ tə bi wɛɹi. ɛɛs sədaɪ də θɪŋz fəɹ ðɛɹ oʊn ɹizənz, ən ðoʊz ɑɹ nɑɾ ɔlweɪz ðə ɹizənz jə θɪŋk."

"Maybe not a hundred," Tam said with a snort, "but a few did come to mind. Only they don't count for much. If Trollocs are after you, you will be safer in Tar Valon than you could ever be here. Just remember to be wary. Aes Sedai do things for their own reasons, and those are not always the reasons you think."

"ðə ɡlimən sɛd sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðæt," ɹænd sɛd sloʊli.

"The gleeman said something like that," Rand said slowly.

"ðɛn i noʊz wʌt hiz tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt. jə lɪsən ʃɑɹp, θɪŋk dip, ən ɡɑɹd jəɹ tʌŋ. ðæts ɡʊɾ ædvaɪs fəɹ ɛni dilɪŋz bɪɑn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, bʌt moʊst ɪspɛʃli wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ. ən wɪð wɔɹɾɝz. tɛl læn sʌmθɪŋ, ən juv əz ɡʊɾ əz toʊl mɔɪɹeɪn. ɪf hiz ə wɔɹɾɝ, ðən hiz bɑndəd tə hɝ əz ʃʊɹ əz ðə sʌn ɹoʊz ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, ən i woʊn kip mɛni sikɹəts fɹəm hɝ, ɪf ɛni."

"Then he knows what he's talking about. You listen sharp, think deep, and guard your tongue. That's good advice for any dealings beyond the Two Rivers, but most especially with Aes Sedai. And with Warders. Tell Lan something, and you've as good as told Moiraine. If he's a Warder, then he's bonded to her as sure as the sun rose this morning, and he won't keep many secrets from her, if any."

ɹænd nu lɪɾəl əbaʊt ðə bɑndɪŋ bɪtwin ɛɛs sədaɪ ən wɔɹɾɝz, ðoʊ ɪt pleɪɾ ə bɪɡ pɑɹɾ ɪn ɛvɹi stɔɹi əbaʊt wɔɹɾɝz i hæɾ ɛvɝ hɝd. ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə paʊɝ, ə ɡɪf tə ðə wɔɹɾɝ, əɹ meɪbi səm sɔɹɾ ʌv ɪkstʃeɪnʒ. ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɡɑɾ ɔl sɔɹts ə bɛnəfɪts, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə stɔɹiz. ðeɪ hil mɔɹ kwɪkli ðən ʌðɝ mɛn, ən kəd ɡoʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɪθaʊt fuɾ əɹ wɔɾɝ əɹ slip. səpoʊzədli ðeɪ kəd sɛns tʃɹɑləks, ɪf ðeɪ wɝ kloʊs ɪnʌf, ən ʌðɝ kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, tu, wɪtʃ ɪkspleɪn haʊ læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn hæd tʃɹaɪd tə wɔɹn ðə vɪlədʒ bɪfɔɹ ði ətæk. əz tə wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡɑɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt, ðə stɔɹiz wɝ saɪlənt, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə bɪliv ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ɡɛt sʌmθɪŋ.

Rand knew little about the bonding between Aes Sedai and Warders, though it played a big part in every story about Warders he had ever heard. It was something to do with the Power, a gift to the Warder, or maybe some sort of exchange. The Warders got all sorts of benefits, according to the stories. They healed more quickly than other men, and could go longer without food or water or sleep. Supposedly they could sense Trollocs, if they were close enough, and other creatures of the Dark One, too, which explained how Lan and Moiraine had tried to warn the village before the attack. As to what the Aes Sedai got out of it, the stories were silent, but he was not about to believe they did not get something.

"aɪl bi kɛɹfəl," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ dʒʌst wɪʃ aɪ nu waɪ. ɪt dʌzn meɪk ɛni sɛns. waɪ mi? waɪ ʌs?"

"I'll be careful," Rand said. "I just wish I knew why. It doesn't make any sense. Why me? Why us?"

"aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu, tu, bɔɪ. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu." tæm saɪd hɛvəli. "wɛl, noʊ jus tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊɾ ə bɹoʊkən ɛɡ bæk ɪn ðə ʃɛl, aɪ səpoʊz. haʊ sun juv tə ɡoʊ? əl bi bæk ɑn maɪ fiɾ ɪn ə deɪ əɹ tu, ən wi kən si əbaʊt stɑɹɾɪŋ ə nu flɑk. ɔɹən daʊtʃɹi hæz səm ɡʊd stɑk i maɪt bi wɪlɪŋ tə pɑɹt wɪð, wɪð ðə pæstʃɝz ɔl ɡɔn, ən soʊ dʌz dʒɑn θeɪn."

"I wish I knew, too, boy. Blood and ashes, I wish I knew." Tam sighed heavily. "Well, no use trying to put a broken egg back in the shell, I suppose. How soon do you have to go? I'll be back on my feet in a day or two, and we can see about starting a new flock. Oren Dautry has some good stock he might be willing to part with, with the pastures all gone, and so does Jon Thane."

"mɔɪɹeɪn . . . ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd jə hæd tə steɪ ɪn bɛd. ʃi sɛd wiks." tæm oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, bʌt ɹænd wɛn ɑn. "ænd ʃi tɔk tə mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ."

"Moiraine . . . the Aes Sedai said you had to stay in bed. She said weeks." Tam opened his mouth, but Rand went on. "And she talked to Mistress al'Vere."

"oʊ. wɛl, meɪbi aɪ kən tɔk mɛɹɪn ɝaʊnd." tæm dɪd nɑt saʊn hoʊpfəl ʌv ɪt, ðoʊ. hi ɡeɪv ɹænd ə ʃɑɹp lʊk. "ðə weɪ jə əvɔɪɾəd ænsɝɪŋ minz juv tə liv sun. təmɑɹoʊ? əɹ tənaɪt?"

"Oh. Well, maybe I can talk Marin around." Tam did not sound hopeful of it, though. He gave Rand a sharp look. "The way you avoided answering means you have to leave soon. Tomorrow? Or tonight?"

"tənaɪt," ɹænd sɛd kwaɪətli, ən tæm nɑɾəd sædli.

"Tonight," Rand said quietly, and Tam nodded sadly.

"jɛs. wɛl, ɪf ɪt mʌs bi dʌn, bɛs nɑt tə dɪleɪ. bʌt wɪl si əbaʊt ðɪs 'wiks' bɪznəs." hi plʌkt əɾ ɪz blæŋkəts wɪð mɔɹ ɪɹɪteɪʃən ðən stʃɹɛŋkθ. "pɝhæps əl fɑloʊ ɪn ə fju deɪz ɛniweɪ. kætʃ jə ʌp ɑn ðə ɹoʊd. wɪl si ɪf mɛɹɪn kən kip mi ɪn bɛd wən aɪ wɑnə ɡɛɾ ʌp."

"Yes. Well, if it must be done, best not to delay. But we will see about this 'weeks' business." He plucked at his blankets with more irritation than strength. "Perhaps I'll follow in a few days anyway. Catch you up on the road. We will see if Marin can keep me in bed when I want to get up."

ðəɹ wɑz ə tæp ət ðə dɔɹ, ən læn stʌk ɪz hɛɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum. "seɪ jəɹ ɡʊdbaɪz kwɪkli, ʃifɝɾɝ, ən kʌm. ðəɹ meɪ bi tʃɹʌbəl."

There was a tap at the door, and Lan stuck his head into the room. "Say your goodbyes quickly, sheepherder, and come. There may be trouble."

"tʃɹʌbəl?" ɹænd sɛd, ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɡɹaʊld əɾ ɪm ɪmpeɪʃənli.

"Trouble?" Rand said, and the Warder growled at him impatiently.

"dʒʌs hɝi!"

"Just hurry!"

heɪstəli ɹænd snætʃt ʌp ɪz kloʊk. hi stɑɹɾəd tə əndu ðə sɔɹd bɛlt, bʌt tæm spoʊk ʌp.

Hastily Rand snatched up his cloak. He started to undo the sword belt, but Tam spoke up.

"kip ɪt. jəl pɹɑbli hæv mɔɹ niɾ ʌv ɪt ðən aɪ, ðoʊ, ðə laɪt wɪlɪŋ, niðɝ ʌv əs wɪl. teɪk kɛɹ, læd. jə hɪɹ?"

"Keep it. You will probably have more need of it than I, though, the Light willing, neither of us will. Take care, lad. You hear?"

ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ lænz kəntɪnjud ɡɹaʊlz, ɹænd bɛn tə ɡɹæb tæm ɪn ə hʌɡ. "aɪ wɪl kʌm bæk. aɪ pɹɑməs jə ðæt."

Ignoring Lan's continued growls, Rand bent to grab Tam in a hug. "I will come back. I promise you that."

"ʌv kɔɹs jə wɪl." tæm læft. hi ɹɪtɝn ðə hʌɡ wikli, ən ɛndəd baɪ pæɾɪŋ ɹænd ɑn ðə bæk. "aɪ noʊ ðæt. ən əl əv twaɪs əz mɛni ʃip fəɹ jə tə tɛnd wən jə ɹɪtɝn. naʊ ɡoʊ, bɪfɔɹ ðət fɛloʊ dʌz hɪmsɛlf ən ɪnʒɝi."

"Of course you will." Tam laughed. He returned the hug weakly, and ended by patting Rand on the back. "I know that. And I'll have twice as many sheep for you to tend when you return. Now go, before that fellow does himself an injury."

ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə hæŋ bæk, tʃɹaɪd tə faɪn ðə wɝdz fəɹ ðə kwɛstʃən i dɪd nɑt wɑnə æsk, bʌt læn ɛntɝd ðə ɹum tə kætʃ ɪm baɪ ði ɑɹm ən pʊl ɪm ɪndə ðə hɔl. ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæd dɑn ə dʌl ɡɹeɪ-ɡɹin tunɪk ʌv oʊvɝlæpɪŋ mɛɾəl skeɪlz. hɪz vɔɪs ɹæspt wɪð ɪɹɪteɪʃən.

Rand tried to hang back, tried to find the words for the question he did not want to ask, but Lan entered the room to catch him by the arm and pull him into the hall. The Warder had donned a dull gray-green tunic of overlapping metal scales. His voice rasped with irritation.

"wi hæv tə hɝi. doʊn jə ʌndɝstæn ðə wɝd tʃɹʌbəl?"

"We have to hurry. Don't you understand the word trouble?"

aʊtsaɪd ðə ɹum mæt weɪɾəd, kloʊkt ən koʊɾəd ən kæɹiɪŋ ɪz baʊ. ə kwɪvɝ hʌŋ əɾ ɪz weɪst. hi wɑz ɹɑkɪŋ æŋkʃəsli ɑn ɪz hilz, ən i kɛpt ɡlænsɪŋ ɔf təwɔɹd ðə stɛɹz wɪð wʌt sim tə bi ikwəl pɑɹts ɪmpeɪʃəns ən fɪɹ. "ðɪs ɪzən mʌtʃ laɪk ðə stɔɹiz, ɹænd, ɪz ɪt?" hi sɛd hɔɹsli.

Outside the room Mat waited, cloaked and coated and carrying his bow. A quiver hung at his waist. He was rocking anxiously on his heels, and he kept glancing off toward the stairs with what seemed to be equal parts impatience and fear. "This isn't much like the stories, Rand, is it?" he said hoarsely.

"wʌt kaɪndə tʃɹʌbəl?" ɹænd dɪmændəd, bʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɹæn əhɛɾ ə hɪm ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ænsɝɪŋ, teɪkɪŋ ðə stɛps daʊn tu əɾ ə taɪm. mæt dæʃt æftɝ ɪm wɪð kwɪk dʒɛstʃɝz fəɹ ɹænd tə fɑloʊ.

"What kind of trouble?" Rand demanded, but the Warder ran ahead of him instead of answering, taking the steps down two at a time. Mat dashed after him with quick gestures for Rand to follow.

ʃɹʌɡɪŋ ɪndə hɪz kloʊk, hi kɑɾ ʌp tə ðɛm daʊnstɛɹz. oʊnli ə fibəl laɪt fɪl ðə kɑmən ɹum; hæf ðə kændəlz hæd bɝn aʊɾ ən moʊst ə ðə ɹɛst wɝ ɡʌɾɝɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm. mæt stʊd nɛks tə wʌn ə ðə fɹʌnt wɪndoʊz, pipɪŋ aʊɾ əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə bi sin. læn hɛl ðə dɔɹ oʊpən ə kɹæk ən pɪɹɾ ɪndə ði ɪn jɑɹd.

Shrugging into his cloak, he caught up to them downstairs. Only a feeble light filled the common room; half the candles had burned out and most of the rest were guttering. It was empty except for the three of them. Mat stood next to one of the front windows, peeping out as if trying not to be seen. Lan held the door open a crack and peered into the inn yard.

wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ kəd bi wɑtʃɪŋ, ɹænd wɛn tə dʒɔɪn hɪm. ðə wɔɹɾɝ mʌɾɝd əɾ ɪm tə teɪk ə kɛɹ, bʌɾ i dɪɾ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ə tʃɹaɪfəl waɪɾɝ tə meɪk ɹum fəɹ ɹænd tə lʊk, tu.

Wondering what they could be watching, Rand went to join him. The Warder muttered at him to take a care, but he did open the door a trifle wider to make room for Rand to look, too.

ət fɝst i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪɡzækli wʌɾ i wɑz siɪŋ. ə kɹaʊɾ ə vɪlədʒ mɛn, səm θɹi dʌzən əɹ soʊ, klʌstɝd nɪɹ ðə bɝnd-aʊt hʌsk ə ðə pɛdlɝz wæɡən, naɪt pʊʃt bæk baɪ ðə tɔɹtʃɪz səm ə ðɛm kæɹid. mɔɪɹeɪn feɪs ðɛm, hɝ bæk tə ði ɪn, linɪŋ wɪð simɪŋ kæʒəɑlnəs ɑn əɹ wɔkɪŋ stæf. hɑɹi kɑplɪn stʊɾ ɪn ðə fɹʌn ə ðə kɹaʊd wɪð ɪz bɹʌðɝ, dɑɹl, ən bili kɔŋɡɝ. sɛn bui wɑz ðɛɹ, əz wɛl, lʊkɪŋ ənkʌmftəɹbəl. ɹænd wɑz stɑɹɾəld tə si hɑɹi ʃeɪk ɪz fɪst ət mɔɪɹeɪn.

At first he was not sure exactly what he was seeing. A crowd of village men, some three dozen or so, clustered near the burned-out husk of the peddler's wagon, night pushed back by the torches some of them carried. Moiraine faced them, her back to the inn, leaning with seeming casualness on her walking staff. Hari Coplin stood in the front of the crowd with his brother, Darl, and Bili Congar. Cenn Buie was there, as well, looking uncomfortable. Rand was startled to see Hari shake his fist at Moiraine.

"liv ɛmənz fild!" ðə saʊɝ-feɪs fɑɹmɝ ʃaʊɾəd. ə fju vɔɪsəz ɪn ðə kɹaʊɾ ɛkoʊd hɪm, bʌt hɛzɪɾəntli, ən noʊ wʌn pʊʃt fɔɹwɝd. ðeɪ maɪt bi wɪlɪŋ tə kənfɹʌn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ fɹəm wɪðɪn ə kɹaʊd, bʌt nʌn ə ðɛm wɑntəd tə bi sɪŋɡəld aʊt. nɑt baɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu hæɾ ɛvɹi ɹizən tə teɪk əfɛns.

"Leave Emond's Field!" the sour-faced farmer shouted. A few voices in the crowd echoed him, but hesitantly, and no one pushed forward. They might be willing to confront an Aes Sedai from within a crowd, but none of them wanted to be singled out. Not by an Aes Sedai who had every reason to take offense.

"ju bɹɔt ðoʊz mɑnstɝz!" dɑɹl ɹɔɹd. hi weɪvd ə tɔɹtʃ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd, ən ðəɹ wɝ ʃaʊts ʌv, "ju bɹɔt ðɛm!" ən "ɪts jəɹ fɔlt!" lɛd baɪ hɪz kʌzən bili.

"You brought those monsters!" Darl roared. He waved a torch over his head, and there were shouts of, "You brought them!" and "It's your fault!" led by his cousin Bili.

hɑɹi ɛlboʊd sɛn bui, ən ði oʊl θætʃɝ pɝst ɪz lɪps ən ɡeɪv ɪm ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlɛɹ. "ðoʊz θɪŋz . . . ðoʊz tʃɹɑləks dɪdn əpɪɹ əntɪl æftɝ jə keɪm," sɛn mʌɾɝd, bɛɹli laʊɾ ɪnʌf tə bi hɝd. hi swʌŋ ɪz hɛd fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd dɔɹli əz ɪf wɪʃɪŋ i wɝ sʌmwɛɹ ɛls ən lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ə weɪ tə ɡɛt ðɛɹ. "jɔɹ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. wi wɑnt nʌn ə jəɹ sɔɹɾ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ɛɛs sədaɪ bɹɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl ɑn ðɛɹ bæks. ɪf jə steɪ, jəl oʊnli bɹɪŋ mɔɹ."

Hari elbowed Cenn Buie, and the old thatcher pursed his lips and gave him a sidelong glare. "Those things . . . those Trollocs didn't appear until after you came," Cenn muttered, barely loud enough to be heard. He swung his head from side to side dourly as if wishing he were somewhere else and looking for a way to get there. "You're an Aes Sedai. We want none of your sort in the Two Rivers. Aes Sedai bring trouble on their backs. If you stay, you will only bring more."

hɪz spitʃ bɹɔt noʊ ɹɪspɑns fɹəm ðə ɡæðɝd vɪlɪdʒɝz, ən hɑɹi skaʊld ɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. əbɹʌpli hi snætʃt dɑɹlz tɔɹtʃ ən ʃʊk ɪɾ ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən. "ɡɛɾ aʊt!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. "ɔɹ wɪl bɝn jə aʊt!"

His speech brought no response from the gathered villagers, and Hari scowled in frustration. Abruptly he snatched Darl's torch and shook it in her direction. "Get out!" he shouted. "Or we'll burn you out!"

dɛd saɪləns fɛl, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə ʃʌflɪŋ ʌv ə fju fiɾ əz mɛn dʒɹu bæk. tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk kəd faɪt bæk ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ətækt, bʌt vaɪələns wɑz fɑɹ fɹəm kɑmən, ən θɹɛɾənɪŋ pipəl wɑz fɔɹən tə ðɛm, bɪɑn ði əkeɪʒənəl ʃeɪkɪŋ ʌv ə fɪst. sɛn bui, bili kɔŋɡɝ, ən ðə kɑplɪnz wɝ lɛft aʊt fɹʌn əloʊn. bili lʊkt əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə bæk əweɪ, tu.

Dead silence fell, except for the shuffling of a few feet as men drew back. Two Rivers folk could fight back if they were attacked, but violence was far from common, and threatening people was foreign to them, beyond the occasional shaking of a fist. Cenn Buie, Bili Congar, and the Coplins were left out front alone. Bili looked as if he wanted to back away, too.

hɑɹi ɡeɪv ən ənizi stɑɹɾ ət ðə læk ə səpɔɹt, bʌɾ i ɹəkʌvɝd kwɪkli. "ɡɛɾ aʊt!" hi ʃaʊɾəd əɡɛn, ɛkoʊd baɪ dɑɹl ænd, mɔɹ wikli, baɪ bili. hɑɹi ɡlɛɹɾ ət ði ʌðɝz. moʊst ə ðə kɹaʊd feɪl tə miɾ ɪz aɪ.

Hari gave an uneasy start at the lack of support, but he recovered quickly. "Get out!" he shouted again, echoed by Darl and, more weakly, by Bili. Hari glared at the others. Most of the crowd failed to meet his eye.

sʌɾənli bɹæn ælvɪɹ ən hɹəl luhən muvd aʊɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊz, stɑpɪŋ əpɑɹt fɹəm boʊθ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə kɹaʊd. ɪn wʌn hæn ðə meɪɝ kæʒəwəli kæɹid ðə bɪɡ wʊɾən mɔl i juz tə dʒɹaɪv spɪɡəts ɪndə kæsks. "dɪd sʌmwʌn sədʒɛs bɝnɪŋ maɪ ɪn?" hi æsk sɔfli.

Suddenly Bran al'Vere and Haral Luhhan moved out of the shadows, stopping apart from both the Aes Sedai and the crowd. In one hand the Mayor casually carried the big wooden maul he used to drive spigots into casks. "Did someone suggest burning my inn?" he asked softly.

ðə tu kɑplɪnz tʊk ə stɛp bæk, ən sɛn bui ɛdʒd əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm. bili kɔŋɡɝ daɪvd ɪndə ðə kɹaʊd. "nɑt ðæt," dɑɹl sɛd kwɪkli. "wi nɛvɝ sɛd ðæt, bɹæn . . . ɑ, meɪɝ."

The two Coplins took a step back, and Cenn Buie edged away from them. Bili Congar dived into the crowd. "Not that," Darl said quickly. "We never said that, Bran . . . ah, Mayor."

bɹæn nɑɾəd. "ðɛn pɝhæps aɪ hɝd jə θɹɛɾənɪŋ tə hɑɹm ɡɛsts ɪn maɪ ɪn?"

Bran nodded. "Then perhaps I heard you threatening to harm guests in my inn?"

"ʃiz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ," hɑɹi bɪɡæn æŋɡɹəli, bʌɾ ɪz wɝdz kʌɾ ɔf əz hɹəl luhən muvd.

"She's an Aes Sedai," Hari began angrily, but his words cut off as Haral Luhhan moved.

ðə blæksmɪθ sɪmpli stʃɹɛtʃt, θɹʌstɪŋ θɪk ɑɹmz oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd, taɪɾənɪŋ mæsɪv fɪsts əntɪl ɪz nʌkəlz kɹækt, bʌt hɑɹi lʊkt ət ðə bɝli mæn əz ɪf wʌn ə ðoʊz fɪsts hæd bɪn ʃeɪkən ʌndɝ ɪz noʊz. hɹəl foʊldəɾ ɪz ɑɹmz əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst. "jɔɹ pɑɹɾən, hɑɹi. aɪ dɪd nɑt min tə kʌt jə ɔf. jə wɝ seɪɪŋ?"

The blacksmith simply stretched, thrusting thick arms over his head, tightening massive fists until his knuckles cracked, but Hari looked at the burly man as if one of those fists had been shaken under his nose. Haral folded his arms across his chest. "Your pardon, Hari. I did not mean to cut you off. You were saying?"

bʌt hɑɹi, ʃoʊldɝz hʌntʃt əz ðoʊ hi wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒɹɔ ɪndə hɪmsɛlf ən dɪsəpɪɹ, sim tə hæv nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ tə seɪ.

But Hari, shoulders hunched as though he were trying to draw into himself and disappear, seemed to have nothing more to say.

"aɪm sɝpɹaɪzd ət jə pipəl," bɹæn ɹʌmbəld. "pəɾ ɑlkɑɹ, jəɹ bɔɪz lɛɡ wɑz bɹoʊkən læs naɪt, bʌɾ aɪ sɔ hɪm wɔkɪŋ ɑn ɪt tədeɪ - kəz ə hɝ. juwɔɝd kændwɪn, jə wɝ laɪɪŋ ɑn jəɹ bɛli wɪð ə ɡæʃ daʊn jəɹ bæk laɪk ə fɪʃ fəɹ klinɪŋ, tɪl ʃi leɪd hænz ɑn ju. naʊ ɪt lʊks əz ɪf ɪt hæpən ə mʌnθ əɡoʊ, ən ənlɛs aɪ mɪsdaʊt ðɛɹəl bɛɹli bi ə skɑɹ. ən ju, sɛn." ðə θætʃɝ stɑɹɾəd tə feɪd bæk ɪndə ðə kɹaʊd, bʌt stɑpt, hɛld ənkʌmftəbli baɪ bɹænz ɡeɪz. "aɪd bi ʃɑk tə si ɛni mæn ɑn ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl hɪɹ, sɛn, bʌt jə moʊst ʌv ɔl. jəɹ ɑɹm wəd stɪl bi hæŋɪŋ jusləs ət jəɹ saɪd, ə mæs ə bɝnz ən bɹuzəz, ɪf nɑt fəɹ hɝ. ɪf juv noʊ ɡɹæɾətud, hæv jə noʊ ʃeɪm?"

"I'm surprised at you people," Bran rumbled. "Paet al'Caar, your boy's leg was broken last night, but I saw him walking on it today - because of her. Eward Candwin, you were lying on your belly with a gash down your back like a fish for cleaning, till she laid hands on you. Now it looks as if it happened a month ago, and unless I misdoubt there'll barely be a scar. And you, Cenn." The thatcher started to fade back into the crowd, but stopped, held uncomfortably by Bran's gaze. "I'd be shocked to see any man on the Village Council here, Cenn, but you most of all. Your arm would still be hanging useless at your side, a mass of burns and bruises, if not for her. If you have no gratitude, have you no shame?"

sɛn hæf lɪftəɾ ɪz ɹaɪt hænd, ðən lʊkt əweɪ fɹəm ɪɾ æŋɡɹəli. "aɪ kænɑt dɪnaɪ wʌt ʃi dɪd," hi mʌɾɝd, ən i dɪd saʊn əʃeɪmd. "ʃi hɛlp mi, ən ʌðɝz," hi wɛn ɑn ɪn ə pliɾɪŋ toʊn, "bʌt ʃiz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, bɹæn. ɪf ðoʊz tʃɹɑləks dɪdn kʌm kəz ə hɝ, waɪ dɪd ðeɪ kʌm? wi wɑnt noʊ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. lɛɾ əm kip ðɛɹ tʃɹʌbəlz əweɪ fɹəm ʌs."

Cenn half lifted his right hand, then looked away from it angrily. "I cannot deny what she did," he muttered, and he did sound ashamed. "She helped me, and others," he went on in a pleading tone, "but she's an Aes Sedai, Bran. If those Trollocs didn't come because of her, why did they come? We want no part of Aes Sedai in the Two Rivers. Let them keep their troubles away from us."

ə fju mɛn, seɪfli bæk ɪn ðə kɹaʊd, ʃaʊɾəd ðɛn. "wi wɑnt noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ tʃɹʌbəlz!" "sɛn əɹ əweɪ!" "dʒɹaɪv əɹ aʊt!" "waɪ dɪd ðeɪ kʌm ɪf nɑt kəz ə hɝ?"

A few men, safely back in the crowd, shouted then. "We want no Aes Sedai troubles!" "Send her away!" "Drive her out!" "Why did they come if not because of her?"

ə skaʊl ɡɹu ɑn bɹænz feɪs, bʌt bɪfɔɹ i kəd spik mɔɪɹeɪn sʌɾənli wɝld əɹ vaɪn-kɑɹv stæf əbʌv əɹ hɛd, spɪnɪŋ ɪt wɪð boʊθ hænz. ɹændz ɡæsp ɛkoʊd ðəɾ ə ðə vɪlɪdʒɝz, fəɹ ə hɪsɪŋ waɪt fleɪm flɛɹd fɹəm itʃ ɛn ə ðə stæf, stændɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt laɪk spɪɹpɔɪns dɪspaɪt ðə ɹɑdz wɝlɪŋ. ivən bɹæn ən hɹəl ɛdʒd əweɪ fɹəm hɝ. ʃi snæpt əɹ ɑɹmz daʊn stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt bɪfɔɹ hɝ, ðə stæf pɛɹəlɛl tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, bʌt ðə peɪl faɪɝ stɪl dʒɛɾɪd aʊt, bɹaɪɾɝ ðən ðə tɔɹtʃɪz. mɛn ʃaɪɾ əweɪ, hɛld ʌp hænz tə ʃil ðɛɹ aɪz fɹəm ðə peɪn ə ðət bɹɪljəns.

A scowl grew on Bran's face, but before he could speak Moiraine suddenly whirled her vine-carved staff above her head, spinning it with both hands. Rand's gasp echoed that of the villagers, for a hissing white flame flared from each end of the staff, standing straight out like spearpoints despite the rod's whirling. Even Bran and Haral edged away from her. She snapped her arms down straight out before her, the staff parallel to the ground, but the pale fire still jetted out, brighter than the torches. Men shied away, held up hands to shield their eyes from the pain of that brilliance.

"ɪz ðɪs wʌɾ æɛmənz blʌɾ əz kʌm tə?" ði ɛɛs sədaɪz vɔɪs wɑz nɑt laʊd, bʌɾ ɪɾ oʊvɝwɛlmd ɛvɹi ʌðɝ saʊnd. "lɪɾəl pipəl skwɑbəlɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɹaɪt tə haɪd laɪk ɹæbəts? juv fɝɡɑɾən u jə wɝ, fɝɡɑɾən wʌt jə wɝ, bʌɾ aɪ hæd hoʊp səm smɔl pɑɹt wɑz lɛft, səm mɛmɹi ɪn blʌɾ ən boʊn. səm ʃɹɛd tə stil jə fəɹ ðə lɔŋ naɪt kʌmɪŋ."

"Is this what Aemon's blood has come to?" The Aes Sedai's voice was not loud, but it overwhelmed every other sound. "Little people squabbling for the right to hide like rabbits? You have forgotten who you were, forgotten what you were, but I had hoped some small part was left, some memory in blood and bone. Some shred to steel you for the long night coming."

noʊ wʌn spoʊk. ðə tu kɑplɪnz lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ nɛvɝ wɑntəd tə oʊpən ðɛɹ maʊðz əɡɛn.

No one spoke. The two Coplins looked as if they never wanted to open their mouths again.

bɹæn sɛd, "fɝɡɑɾən u wi wɝ? wəɹ u wi ɔlweɪz əv bɪn. ɑnəs fɑɹmɝz ən ʃɛpɝdz ən kɹæfsmən. tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk."

Bran said, "Forgotten who we were? We are who we always have been. Honest farmers and shepherds and craftsmen. Two Rivers folk."

"tə ðə saʊθ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "laɪz ðə ɹɪvɝ jə kɔl ðə waɪt ɹɪvɝ, bʌt fɑɹ tə ði ist ə hɪɹ mɛn kɔl ɪt stɪl baɪ ɪts ɹaɪtfəl neɪm. meɪnɛðɹəndʒɹɛl. ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, wɔɾɝz ə ðə maʊntən hoʊm. spɑɹklɪŋ wɔɾɝz ðət wʌns kɔɹs θɹu ə læn ə bɹeɪvɝi ən bjuɾi. tu θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ meɪnɛðɹəndʒɹɛl floʊd baɪ ðə wɔlz ʌv ə maʊntən sɪɾi soʊ lʌvli tə bɪhoʊl ðəɾ oʊɡiɝ stoʊnmeɪsɑnz keɪm tə stɛɹ ɪn wʌndɝ. fɑɹmz ən vɪlədʒəz kʌvɝd ðɪs ɹidʒən, ən ðət jə kɔl ðə fɔɹəst ə ʃædoʊz, əz wɛl, ən bɪɑnd. bʌɾ ɔl ə ðoʊz foʊk θɔɾ ə ðɛmsɛlvz əz ðə pipəl ə ðə maʊntən hoʊm, ðə pipəl ə meɪnɛðɝən.

"To the south," Moiraine said, "lies the river you call the White River, but far to the east of here men call it still by its rightful name. Manetherendrelle. In the Old Tongue, Waters of the Mountain Home. Sparkling waters that once coursed through a land of bravery and beauty. Two thousand years ago Manetherendrelle flowed by the walls of a mountain city so lovely to behold that Ogier stonemasons came to stare in wonder. Farms and villages covered this region, and that you call the Forest of Shadows, as well, and beyond. But all of those folk thought of themselves as the people of the Mountain Home, the people of Manetheren.

"ðɛɹ kɪŋ wɑz æɛmən æl kɑɹ æl θɔɹɪn, æɛmən sʌn ə kɑɹ sʌn ə θɔɹɪn, ən ɛldʒɹin eɪ ɛlən eɪ kɑɹlən wɑz ɪz kwin. æɛmən, ə mæn soʊ fɪɹləs ðət ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst kɑmpləmən fəɹ kɝədʒ ɛni kəd ɡɪv, ivən əmʌŋ ɪz ɛnəmiz, wɑz tə seɪ ə mæn hæɾ æɛmənz hɑɹt. ɛldʒɹin, soʊ bjuɾəfəl ðəɾ ɪt wɑz sɛd ðə flaʊɝz blum tə meɪk əɹ smaɪl. bɹeɪvɝi ən bjuɾi ən wɪzdəm ən ə lʌv ðət dɛθ kəd nɑt sʌndɝ. wip, ɪf juv ə hɑɹt, fəɹ ðə lɔs ə ðɛm, fəɹ ðə lɔs ʌv ivən ðɛɹ mɛmɹi. wip, fəɹ ðə lɔs ə ðɛɹ blʌd."

"Their King was Aemon al Caar al Thorin, Aemon son of Caar son of Thorin, and Eldrene ay Ellan ay Carlan was his Queen. Aemon, a man so fearless that the greatest compliment for courage any could give, even among his enemies, was to say a man had Aemon's heart. Eldrene, so beautiful that it was said the flowers bloomed to make her smile. Bravery and beauty and wisdom and a love that death could not sunder. Weep, if you have a heart, for the loss of them, for the loss of even their memory. Weep, for the loss of their blood."

ʃi fɛl saɪlən ðɛn, bʌt noʊ wʌn spoʊk. ɹænd wɑz əz baʊn əz ði ʌðɝz ɪn ðə spɛl ʃi hæd kɹieɪɾəd. wən ʃi spoʊk əɡɛn, hi dʒɹæŋk ɪɾ ɪn, ən soʊ dɪd ðə ɹɛst.

She fell silent then, but no one spoke. Rand was as bound as the others in the spell she had created. When she spoke again, he drank it in, and so did the rest.

"fɔɹ nɪɹli tu sɛntʃɝiz ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz hæd ɹævɪdʒ ðə lɛŋθ ən bɹɛdθ ə ðə wɝld, ən wɛɹɛvɝ bæɾəlz ɹeɪdʒd, ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl bænɝ ə meɪnɛðɝən wɑz ɪn ðə fɔɹfɹʌnt. ðə mɛn ə meɪnɛðɝən wɝ ə θɔɹn tə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz fʊɾ ən ə bɹæmbəl tə hɪz hænd. sɪŋ ə meɪnɛðɝən, ðət wəd nɛvɝ bɛnd ni tə ðə ʃædoʊ. sɪŋ ə meɪnɛðɝən, ðə sɔɹd ðət kəd nɑt bi bɹoʊkən.

"For nearly two centuries the Trolloc Wars had ravaged the length and breadth of the world, and wherever battles raged, the Red Eagle banner of Manetheren was in the forefront. The men of Manetheren were a thorn to the Dark One's foot and a bramble to his hand. Sing of Manetheren, that would never bend knee to the Shadow. Sing of Manetheren, the sword that could not be broken.

"ðeɪ wɝ fɑɹ əweɪ, ðə mɛn ə meɪnɛðɝən, ɑn ðə fild ə bɛkɑɹ, kɔl ðə fild ə blʌd, wən nuz keɪm ðəɾ ə tʃɹɑlɑk ɑɹmi wɑz muvɪŋ əɡɛns ðɛɹ hoʊm. tu fɑɹ tə də ɛls bʌt weɪt tə hɪɹ ə ðɛɹ lænz dɛθ, fəɹ ðə fɔɹsɪz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn mɛn tə meɪk ən ɛn ə ðɛm. kɪl ðə maɪɾi oʊk baɪ hækɪŋ əweɪ ɪts ɹuts. tu fɑɹ tə də ɛls bʌt mɔɹn. bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ðə mɛn ə ðə maʊntən hoʊm.

"They were far away, the men of Manetheren, on the Field of Bekkar, called the Field of Blood, when news came that a Trolloc army was moving against their home. Too far to do else but wait to hear of their land's death, for the forces of the Dark One meant to make an end of them. Kill the mighty oak by hacking away its roots. Too far to do else but mourn. But they were the men of the Mountain Home.

"wɪθaʊt hɛzəteɪʃən, wɪθaʊt θɔt fəɹ ðə dɪstəns ðeɪ mʌs tʃɹævəl, ðeɪ mɑɹtʃt fɹəm ðə vɛɹi fild ə vɪktɝi, stɪl kʌvɝɾ ɪn dʌst ən swɛɾ ən blʌd. deɪ ən naɪt ðeɪ mɑɹtʃt, fəɹ ðeɪ hæd sin ðə hɔɹɝ ə tʃɹɑlɑk ɑɹmi lɛf bɪhaɪn ɪt, ən noʊ mæn ə ðɛm kəd slip waɪl sətʃ ə deɪnʒɝ θɹɛɾənd meɪnɛðɝən. ðeɪ muvd əz ɪf ðɛɹ fit hæd wɪŋz, mɑɹtʃɪŋ fɝðɝ ən fæstɝ ðən fɹɛnz hoʊpt əɹ ɛnəmiz fɪɹd ðeɪ kʊd. əɾ ɛni ʌðɝ deɪ ðət mɑɹtʃ əloʊn wʊɾə ɪnspaɪɝd sɔŋz. wən ðə dɑɹk wʌnz ɑɹmiz swup daʊn əpɑn ðə lænz ə meɪnɛðɝən, ðə mɛn ə ðə maʊntən hoʊm stʊd bɪfɔɹ ɪt, wɪð ðɛɹ bæks tə ðə tɛɹɛndʒɹɛl."

"Without hesitation, without thought for the distance they must travel, they marched from the very field of victory, still covered in dust and sweat and blood. Day and night they marched, for they had seen the horror a Trolloc army left behind it, and no man of them could sleep while such a danger threatened Manetheren. They moved as if their feet had wings, marching further and faster than friends hoped or enemies feared they could. At any other day that march alone would have inspired songs. When the Dark One's armies swooped down upon the lands of Manetheren, the men of the Mountain Home stood before it, with their backs to the Tarendrelle."

səm vɪlɪdʒɝ ɹeɪzd ə smɔl tʃɪɹ ðɛn, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn kɛpt ɑn əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt hɝd. "ðə hoʊs ðət feɪs ðə mɛn ə meɪnɛðɝən wɑz ɪnʌf tə dɔn ðə bɹeɪvəs hɑɹt. ɹeɪvənz blækən ðə skaɪ; tʃɹɑləks blækən ðə lænd. tʃɹɑləks ən ðɛɹ hjumən ælaɪz. tʃɹɑləks ən dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪn tɛnz ə tɛnz ə θaʊzənz, ən dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz tə kəmænd. ət naɪt ðɛɹ kʊk-faɪɝz aʊtnʌmbɝd ðə stɑɹz, ən dɔn ɹɪvil ðə bænɝ ə bælzəmən ət ðɛɹ hɛd. bælzəmən, hɑɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk. ən eɪntʃənt neɪm fəɹ ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz. ðə dɑɹk wʌn kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn fɹi ʌv ɪz pɹɪzən ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, fəɹ ɪf i hæd bɪn, nɑɾ ɔl ðə fɔɹsɪz ə hjumənkaɪn təɡɛðɝ cʊɾə stʊɾ əɡɛns hɪm, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz paʊɝ ðɛɹ. dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz, ən səm ivəl ðət meɪd ðət laɪt-dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ bænɝ sim noʊ mɔɹ ðən ɹaɪɾ ən sɛn ə tʃɪl ɪndə ðə soʊlz ə ðə mɛn u feɪst ɪt.

Some villager raised a small cheer then, but Moiraine kept on as if she had not heard. "The host that faced the men of Manetheren was enough to daunt the bravest heart. Ravens blackened the sky; Trollocs blackened the land. Trollocs and their human allies. Trollocs and Darkfriends in tens of tens of thousands, and Dreadlords to command. At night their cook-fires outnumbered the stars, and dawn revealed the banner of Ba'alzamon at their head. Ba'alzamon, Heart of the Dark. An ancient name for the Father of Lies. The Dark One could not have been free of his prison at Shayol Ghul, for if he had been, not all the forces of humankind together could have stood against him, but there was power there. Dreadlords, and some evil that made that light-destroying banner seem no more than right and sent a chill into the souls of the men who faced it.

"jɛt, ðeɪ nu wʌt ðeɪ mʌs du. ðɛɹ hoʊmlæn leɪ dʒʌst əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ. ðeɪ mʌs kip ðət hoʊst, ən ðə paʊɝ wɪð ɪt, fɹəm ðə maʊntən hoʊm. æɛmən hæd sɛn aʊt mɛsənʒɝz. eɪd wɑz pɹɑməst ɪf ðeɪ kəd hoʊl fəɹ bʌt θɹi deɪz ət ðə tɛɹɛndʒɹɛl. hoʊl fəɹ θɹi deɪz əɡɛnst ɑdz ðət ʃəɾ oʊvɝwɛlm əm ɪn ðə fɝst aʊɝ. jɛt sʌmhaʊ, θɹu blʌɾi əsɔlt ən dɛspɹɪt dɪfɛns, ðeɪ hɛl θɹu ən aʊɝ, ən ðə sɛkən aʊɝ, ən ðə θɝd. fəɹ θɹi deɪz ðeɪ fɔt, ən ðoʊ ðə læn bɪkeɪm ə bʊtʃɝz jɑɹd, noʊ kɹɔsɪŋ ə ðə tɛɹɛndʒɹɛl dɪd ðeɪ jild. baɪ ðə θɝd naɪt noʊ hɛlp hæd kʌm, ən noʊ mɛsənʒɝz, ən ðeɪ fɔɾ ɑn əloʊn. fəɹ sɪks deɪz. fəɹ naɪn. ən ɑn ðə tɛnθ deɪ æɛmən nu ðə bɪɾɝ teɪst ə bɪtʃɹeɪəl. noʊ hɛlp wɑz kʌmɪŋ, ən ðeɪ kəd hoʊl ðə ɹɪvɝ kɹɔsɪŋz noʊ mɔɹ."

"Yet, they knew what they must do. Their homeland lay just across the river. They must keep that host, and the power with it, from the Mountain Home. Aemon had sent out messengers. Aid was promised if they could hold for but three days at the Tarendrelle. Hold for three days against odds that should overwhelm them in the first hour. Yet somehow, through bloody assault and desperate defense, they held through an hour, and the second hour, and the third. For three days they fought, and though the land became a butcher's yard, no crossing of the Tarendrelle did they yield. By the third night no help had come, and no messengers, and they fought on alone. For six days. For nine. And on the tenth day Aemon knew the bitter taste of betrayal. No help was coming, and they could hold the river crossings no more."

"wʌt dɪd ðeɪ du?" hɑɹi dɪmændəd. tɔɹtʃfaɪɝz flɪkɝɾ ɪn ðə tʃɪl naɪt bɹiz, bʌt noʊ wʌn meɪɾ ə muv tə dʒɹɔ ə kloʊk taɪɾɝ.

"What did they do?" Hari demanded. Torchfires flickered in the chill night breeze, but no one made a move to draw a cloak tighter.

"æɛmən kɹɔs ðə tɛɹɛndʒɹɛl," mɔɪɹeɪn toʊl ðɛm, "dɪstʃɹɔɪɪŋ ðə bɹɪdʒəz bɪhaɪn hɪm. ən i sɛnt wɝd θɹuaʊɾ ɪz læn fəɹ ðə pipəl tə fli, fəɹ i nu ðə paʊɝz wɪð ðə tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹd wəd faɪn ə weɪ tə bɹɪŋ ɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ. ivən əz ðə wɝd wɛn aʊt, ðə tʃɹɑlɑk kɹɔsɪŋ bɪɡæn, ən ðə soʊlʒɝz ə meɪnɛðɝən tʊk ʌp ðə faɪɾ əɡɛn, tə baɪ wɪð ðɛɹ laɪvz wʌɾ aʊɝz ðeɪ kəd fəɹ ðɛɹ pipəl tə ɪskeɪp. fɹəm ðə sɪɾi ʌv meɪnɛðɝən, ɛldʒɹin ɔɹɡənaɪz ðə flaɪɾ ə hɝ pipəl ɪndə ðə dipəs fɔɹəsts ən ðə fæsnəs ə ðə maʊntənz.

"Aemon crossed the Tarendrelle," Moiraine told them, "destroying the bridges behind him. And he sent word throughout his land for the people to flee, for he knew the powers with the Trolloc horde would find a way to bring it across the river. Even as the word went out, the Trolloc crossing began, and the soldiers of Manetheren took up the fight again, to buy with their lives what hours they could for their people to escape. From the city of Manetheren, Eldrene organized the flight of her people into the deepest forests and the fastness of the mountains.

"bʌt səm dɪd nɑt fli. fɝst ɪn ə tʃɹɪkəl, ðən ə ɹɪvɝ, ðən ə flʌd, mɛn wɛnt, nɑt tə seɪfti, bʌt tə dʒɔɪn ði ɑɹmi faɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðɛɹ lænd. ʃɛpɝdz wɪð baʊz, ən fɑɹmɝz wɪð pɪtʃfɔɹks, ən wʊdzmɪn wɪð æksiz. wɪmən wɛnt, tu, ʃoʊldɝɪŋ wʌt wɛpənz ðeɪ kəd faɪn ən mɑɹtʃɪŋ saɪd baɪ saɪd wɪð ðɛɹ mɛn. noʊ wʌn meɪd ðət dʒɝni hu dɪd nɑt noʊ ðeɪ wəd nɛvɝ ɹɪtɝn. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðɛɹ lænd. ɪt hæd bɪn ðɛɹ fɑðɝz', ən ɪt wəd bi ðɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹənz, ən ðeɪ wɛn tə peɪ ðə pɹaɪs ʌv ɪt. nɑɾ ə stɛp ʌv ɡɹaʊnd wɑz ɡɪvən ʌp əntɪl ɪt wɑz soʊkt ɪn blʌd, bʌɾ ət ðə læs ði ɑɹmi ʌv meɪnɛðɝən wɑz dʒɹɪvən bæk, bæk tə hɪɹ, tə ðɪs pleɪs jə naʊ kɔl ɛmənz fild. ən hɪɹ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹdz sɝaʊndəd ðɛm."

"But some did not flee. First in a trickle, then a river, then a flood, men went, not to safety, but to join the army fighting for their land. Shepherds with bows, and farmers with pitchforks, and woodsmen with axes. Women went, too, shouldering what weapons they could find and marching side by side with their men. No one made that journey who did not know they would never return. But it was their land. It had been their fathers', and it would be their children's, and they went to pay the price of it. Not a step of ground was given up until it was soaked in blood, but at the last the army of Manetheren was driven back, back to here, to this place you now call Emond's Field. And here the Trolloc hordes surrounded them."

hɝ vɔɪs hɛl ðə saʊn ə koʊl tɪɹz. "tʃɹɑlɑk dɛɾ ən ðə kɔɹpsəz ə hjumən ɹɛnəɡeɪdz paɪld ʌp ɪn maʊnz, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz mɔɹ skɹæmbəld oʊvɝ ðoʊz tʃɑɹnəl hips ɪn weɪvz ə dɛθ ðət hæd noʊ ɛnd. ðəɹ kəd bi bʌt wʌn fɪnɪʃ. noʊ mæn əɹ wʊmən u hæd stʊd bɪniθ ðə bænɝ ə ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl ət ðət deɪz dɔnɪŋ stɪl lɪvd wən naɪt fɛl. ðə sɔɹd ðət kəd nɑt bi bɹoʊkən wɑz ʃæɾɝd.

Her voice held the sound of cold tears. "Trolloc dead and the corpses of human renegades piled up in mounds, but always more scrambled over those charnel heaps in waves of death that had no end. There could be but one finish. No man or woman who had stood beneath the banner of the Red Eagle at that day's dawning still lived when night fell. The sword that could not be broken was shattered.

"ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst, əloʊn ɪn ði ɛmptid sɪɾi ʌv meɪnɛðɝən, ɛldʒɹin fɛlt æɛmən daɪ, ən əɹ hɑɹt daɪd wɪð hɪm. ən wɛɹ əɹ hɑɹt hæd bɪn wɑz lɛft oʊnli ə θɝs fəɹ vɛnʒəns, vɛnʒəns fəɹ əɹ lʌv, vɛnʒəns fəɹ əɹ pipəl ən əɹ lænd. dʒɹɪvən baɪ ɡɹif ʃi ɹitʃt aʊt tə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, ən hɝl ðə wʌn paʊɝ ət ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ɑɹmi. ən ðəɹ ðə dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz daɪd wɛɹɛvɝ ðeɪ stʊd, wɛðɝ ɪn ðɛɹ sikɹət kaʊnsəlz əɹ ɪɡzɔɹɾɪŋ ðɛɹ soʊlʒɝz. ɪn ðə pæsɪŋ ʌv ə bɹɛθ ðə dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz ən ðə dʒɛnɝəlz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz hoʊs bɝst ɪndə fleɪm. faɪɝ kənsum ðɛɹ bɑɾiz, ən tɛɹɝ kənsum ðɛɹ dʒʌst-vɪktɔɹiəs ɑɹmi.

"In the Mountains of Mist, alone in the emptied city of Manetheren, Eldrene felt Aemon die, and her heart died with him. And where her heart had been was left only a thirst for vengeance, vengeance for her love, vengeance for her people and her land. Driven by grief she reached out to the True Source, and hurled the One Power at the Trolloc army. And there the Dreadlords died wherever they stood, whether in their secret councils or exhorting their soldiers. In the passing of a breath the Dreadlords and the generals of the Dark One's host burst into flame. Fire consumed their bodies, and terror consumed their just-victorious army.

"naʊ ðeɪ ɹæn laɪk bists bɪfɔɹ ə waɪldfaɪɝ ɪn ðə fɔɹəst, wɪð noʊ θɔt fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ ɪskeɪp. nɔɹθ ən saʊθ ðeɪ flɛd. θaʊzənz dʒɹaʊn ətɛmptɪŋ tə kɹɔs ðə tɛɹɛndʒɹɛl wɪθaʊt ði eɪɾ ə ðə dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz, ən ət ðə meɪnɛðɹəndʒɹɛl ðeɪ tɔɹ daʊn ðə bɹɪdʒəz ɪn ðɛɹ fɹaɪɾ ət wʌt maɪt bi fɑloʊɪŋ ðɛm. wɛɹ ðeɪ faʊn pipəl, ðeɪ slu ən bɝnd, bʌt tə fli wɑz ðə nid ðət ɡɹɪp ðɛm. əntɪl, ət læst, noʊ wʌn ə ðɛm ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə lænz ə meɪnɛðɝən. ðeɪ wɝ dɪspɝs laɪk dʌs bɪfɔɹ ðə wɝlwɪnd. ðə faɪnəl vɛnʒəns keɪm mɔɹ sloʊli, bʌɾ ɪt keɪm, wən ðeɪ wɝ hʌntəd daʊn baɪ ʌðɝ pipəlz, baɪ ʌðɝ ɑɹmiz ɪn ʌðɝ lænz. nʌn wɑz lɛft əlaɪv ə ðoʊz u dɪd mɝɾɝ əɾ æɛmənz fild.

"Now they ran like beasts before a wildfire in the forest, with no thought for anything but escape. North and south they fled. Thousands drowned attempting to cross the Tarendrelle without the aid of the Dreadlords, and at the Manetherendrelle they tore down the bridges in their fright at what might be following them. Where they found people, they slew and burned, but to flee was the need that gripped them. Until, at last, no one of them remained in the lands of Manetheren. They were dispersed like dust before the whirlwind. The final vengeance came more slowly, but it came, when they were hunted down by other peoples, by other armies in other lands. None was left alive of those who did murder at Aemon's Field.

"bʌt ðə pɹaɪs wɑz haɪ fəɹ meɪnɛðɝən. ɛldʒɹin hæd dʒɹɔn tə hɝsɛlf mɔɹ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ðən ɛni hjumən kəɾ ɛvɝ hoʊp tə wild əneɪɾɪd. əz ði ɛnəmi dʒɛnɝəlz daɪd, soʊ dɪd ʃi daɪ, ən ðə faɪɝz ðət kənsumd əɹ kənsum ði ɛmpti sɪɾi ʌv meɪnɛðɝən, ivən ðə stoʊnz ʌv ɪt, daʊn tə ðə lɪvɪŋ ɹɑk ə ðə maʊntənz. jɛt ðə pipəl hæd bɪn seɪvd.

"But the price was high for Manetheren. Eldrene had drawn to herself more of the One Power than any human could ever hope to wield unaided. As the enemy generals died, so did she die, and the fires that consumed her consumed the empty city of Manetheren, even the stones of it, down to the living rock of the mountains. Yet the people had been saved.

"nʌθɪŋ wɑz lɛft ə ðɛɹ fɑɹmz, ðɛɹ vɪlədʒəz, əɹ ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪt sɪɾi. səm wəd seɪ ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ lɛft fəɹ ðɛm, nʌθɪŋ bʌt tə fli tə ʌðɝ lænz, wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd bɪɡɪn ənu. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt seɪ soʊ. ðeɪ hæd peɪd sətʃ ə pɹaɪs ɪn blʌɾ ən hoʊp fəɹ ðɛɹ læn əz hæd nɛvɝ bɪn peɪd bɪfɔɹ, ən naʊ ðeɪ wɝ baʊn tə ðət sɔɪl baɪ taɪz stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən stil. ʌðɝ wɔɹz wəd ɹæk əm ɪn jɪɹz tə kʌm, əntɪl ət læs ðɛɹ kɔɹnɝ ə ðə wɝld wɑz fɝɡɑɾən ən ət læs ðeɪ hæd fɝɡɑɾən wɔɹz ən ðə weɪz ʌv wɔɹ. nɛvɝ əɡɛn dɪd meɪnɛðɝən ɹaɪz. ɪts sɔɹɪŋ spaɪɹz ən splæʃɪŋ faʊntənz bɪkeɪm əz ə dʒɹim ðət sloʊli feɪɾəd fɹəm ðə maɪnz ʌv ɪts pipəl. bʌt ðeɪ, ən ðɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹən, ən ðɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹənz tʃɪlʒɹən, hɛl ðə læn ðət wɑz ðɛɹz. ðeɪ hɛld ɪt wən ðə lɔŋ sɛntʃɝiz hæd wɑʃt ðə waɪ ʌv ɪt fɹəm ðɛɹ mɛmɹiz. ðeɪ hɛld ɪɾ əntɪl, tədeɪ, ðəɹ ɪz ju. wip fəɹ meɪnɛðɝən. wip fəɹ wʌɾ ɪz lɔs fɝɛvɝ."

"Nothing was left of their farms, their villages, or their great city. Some would say there was nothing left for them, nothing but to flee to other lands, where they could begin anew. They did not say so. They had paid such a price in blood and hope for their land as had never been paid before, and now they were bound to that soil by ties stronger than steel. Other wars would wrack them in years to come, until at last their corner of the world was forgotten and at last they had forgotten wars and the ways of war. Never again did Manetheren rise. Its soaring spires and splashing fountains became as a dream that slowly faded from the minds of its people. But they, and their children, and their children's children, held the land that was theirs. They held it when the long centuries had washed the why of it from their memories. They held it until, today, there is you. Weep for Manetheren. Weep for what is lost forever."

ðə faɪɝz ɑn mɔɪɹeɪnz stæf wɪŋkt aʊt, ən ʃi loʊɝɾ ɪt tə hɝ saɪɾ əz ɪf ɪt weɪɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd paʊnz. fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmən ðə moʊn ə ðə wɪnd wɑz ði oʊnli saʊnd. ðən pəɾ ɑlkɑɹ ʃoʊldɝd pæs ðə kɑplɪnz.

The fires on Moiraine's staff winked out, and she lowered it to her side as if it weighed a hundred pounds. For a long moment the moan of the wind was the only sound. Then Paet al'Caar shouldered past the Coplins.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ əbaʊt jəɹ stɔɹi," ðə lɔŋ-dʒɔd fɑɹmɝ sɛd. "ɪm noʊ θɔɹn tə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz fʊt, nɔɹ ɛvɝ laɪkli tə bi, niðɝ. bʌt maɪ wɪl ɪz wɔkɪŋ kəz ə ju, ən fəɹ ðəɾ aɪm əʃeɪm tə bi hɪɹ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf jə kən fɝɡɪv mi, bʌt wɛðɝ jəl əɹ noʊ, əl bi ɡoʊɪŋ. ən fəɹ mi, jə kən steɪ ɪn ɛmənz fild əz lɔŋ əz jə laɪk."

"I don't know about your story," the long-jawed farmer said. "I'm no thorn to the Dark One's foot, nor ever likely to be, neither. But my Wil is walking because of you, and for that I am ashamed to be here. I don't know if you can forgive me, but whether you will or no, I'll be going. And for me, you can stay in Emond's Field as long as you like."
