wɪð ə kwɪk dʌk ə hɪz hɛd, ɔlmoʊst ə baʊ, hi pʊʃt bæk θɹu ðə kɹaʊd. ʌðɝz bɪɡæn tə mʌɾɝ ðɛn, ɔfɝɪŋ ʃeɪməfeɪs pɛnɪɾəns bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ, tu, slɪpt əweɪ wʌn baɪ wʌn. ðə kɑplɪnz, saʊɝ-maʊðd ən skaʊlɪŋ wʌns mɔɹ, lʊkt ət ðə feɪsəz ɝaʊn əm ən vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə naɪt wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd. bili kɔŋɡɝ hæd dɪsəpɪɹɾ ivən bɪfɔɹ ɪz kʌzənz.

With a quick duck of his head, almost a bow, he pushed back through the crowd. Others began to mutter then, offering shamefaced penitence before they, too, slipped away one by one. The Coplins, sour-mouthed and scowling once more, looked at the faces around them and vanished into the night without a word. Bili Congar had disappeared even before his cousins.

læn pʊld ɹænd bæk ən ʃʌt ðə dɔɹ. "lɛts ɡoʊ, bɔɪ." ðə wɔɹɾɝ stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə bæk ə ði ɪn. "kʌm əlɔŋ, boʊθ ə ju. kwɪkli!"

Lan pulled Rand back and shut the door. "Let's go, boy." The Warder started for the back of the inn. "Come along, both of you. Quickly!"

ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ ə wʌndɝɪŋ ɡlæns wɪð mæt. waɪl mɔɪɹeɪn hæd bɪn tɛlɪŋ ðə stɔɹi, mæstɝ ælvɪɹz dɝənz kəd nɑɾ əv dʒɹæɡd ɪm əweɪ, bʌt naʊ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls hɛld ɪz fit. ðɪs wɑz ðə ɹil bɪɡɪnɪŋ, livɪŋ ði ɪn ən fɑloʊɪŋ ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɪndə ðə naɪt. . . . hi ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf, ən tʃɹaɪd tə fɝm ɪz ɹizɑlv. hi hæd noʊ tʃɔɪs bʌt tə ɡoʊ, bʌɾ i wəd kʌm bæk tə ɛmənz fild, haʊɛvɝ fɑɹ əɹ lɔŋ ðɪs dʒɝni wɑz.

Rand hesitated, exchanging a wondering glance with Mat. While Moiraine had been telling the story, Master al'Vere's Dhurrans could not have dragged him away, but now something else held his feet. This was the real beginning, leaving the inn and following the Warder into the night. . . . He shook himself, and tried to firm his resolve. He had no choice but to go, but he would come back to Emond's Field, however far or long this journey was.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə weɪɾɪŋ fɔɹ?" læn æsk fɹəm ðə dɔɹ ðət lɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə bæk ə ðə kɑmən ɹum. wɪð ə stɑɹt mæt hɝid tə hɪm.

"What are you waiting for?" Lan asked from the door that led out of the back of the common room. With a start Mat hurried to him.

tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənvɪns hɪmsɛlf ðəɾ i wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə ɡɹæn ædvɛntʃɝ, ɹænd fɑloʊɾ əm θɹu ðə dɑɹkən kɪtʃən ən aʊɾ ɪndə ðə steɪbliɑɹd.

Trying to convince himself that he was beginning a grand adventure, Rand followed them through the darkened kitchen and out into the stableyard.


tʃæptɝ tɛn


CHAPTER 10

livɛteɪkɪŋ


Leavetaking

ə sɪŋɡəl læntɝn, ɪts ʃʌɾɝz hæf kloʊzd, hʌŋ fɹəm ə neɪl ɑn ə stɔl poʊst, kæstɪŋ ə dɪm laɪt. dip ʃædoʊz swɑloʊd moʊst ə ðə stɔlz. əz ɹænd keɪm θɹu ðə dɔɹz fɹəm ðə steɪbliɑɹd, hɑɹɾ ɑn ðə hilz ə mæt ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ, pɛɹɪn lɛpt ʌp ɪn ə ɹʌsəl ə stʃɹɔ fɹəm wɛɹ i hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ wɪð ɪz bæk əɡɛnst ə stɔl dɔɹ. ə hɛvi kloʊk swɑð hɪm.

A single lantern, its shutters half closed, hung from a nail on a stall post, casting a dim light. Deep shadows swallowed most of the stalls. As Rand came through the doors from the stableyard, hard on the heels of Mat and the Warder, Perrin leaped up in a rustle of straw from where he had been sitting with his back against a stall door. A heavy cloak swathed him.

læn bɛɹli pɔz tə dɪmænd, "dɪd jə lʊk ðə weɪ aɪ toʊl ju, blæksmɪθ?"

Lan barely paused to demand, "Did you look the way I told you, blacksmith?"

"aɪ lʊkt," pɛɹɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "ðɛɹz noʊbɑdi hɪɹ bʌɾ ʌs. waɪ wəɾ ɛnibəɾi haɪd - "

"I looked," Perrin replied. "There's nobody here but us. Why would anybody hide - "

"kɛɹ ən ə lɔŋ laɪf ɡoʊ təɡɛðɝ, blæksmɪθ." ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɹæn ə kwɪk aɪ ɝaʊn ðə ʃæɾoʊd steɪbəl ən ðə dipɝ ʃædoʊz ə ðə heɪlɔft əbʌv, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "noʊ taɪm," hi mʌɾɝd, hæf tə hɪmsɛlf. "hɝi, ʃi sɛz."

"Care and a long life go together, blacksmith." The Warder ran a quick eye around the shadowed stable and the deeper shadows of the hayloft above, then shook his head. "No time," he muttered, half to himself. "Hurry, she says."

əz ɪf tə suɾ ɪz wɝdz, hi stʃɹoʊd kwɪkli tə wɛɹ ðə faɪv hɔɹsəz stʊd tɛðɝd, bɹaɪɾəld ən sæɾəld ət ðə bæk ə ðə pul ə laɪt. tu wɝ ðə blæk stæljən ən waɪt mɛɹ ðət ɹænd hæd sin bɪfɔɹ. ði ʌðɝz, ɪf nɑt kwaɪt soʊ tɔl əɹ soʊ slik, sɝɾənli əpɪɹd tə bi əmʌŋ ðə bɛs ðə tu ɹɪvɝz hæd tə ɔfɝ. wɪð heɪsti kɛɹ læn bɪɡæn ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ sɪntʃɪz ən ɡɝθ stʃɹæps, ən ðə lɛðɝ taɪz ðət hɛl sæɾəlbæɡz, wɔɾɝ-skɪnz, ən blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊlz bɪhaɪn ðə sæɾəlz.

As if to suit his words, he strode quickly to where the five horses stood tethered, bridled and saddled at the back of the pool of light. Two were the black stallion and white mare that Rand had seen before. The others, if not quite so tall or so sleek, certainly appeared to be among the best the Two Rivers had to offer. With hasty care Lan began examining cinches and girth straps, and the leather ties that held saddlebags, water-skins, and blanketrolls behind the saddles.

ɹænd ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ʃeɪki smaɪlz wɪð ɪz fɹɛnz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ hɑɹd tə lʊk əz ɪf i ɹɪli wɑz iɡɝ tə bi ɔf.

Rand exchanged shaky smiles with his friends, trying hard to look as if he really was eager to be off.

fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm mæt noʊɾəst ðə sɔɹɾ ət ɹændz weɪst, ən pɔɪntəd tə ɪt. "ju bɪkʌmɪŋ ə wɔɹɾɝ?" hi læft, ðən swɑloʊɾ ɪt wɪð ə kwɪk ɡlæns ət læn. ðə wɔɹɾɝ əpɛɹənli tʊk noʊ noʊɾəs. "ɔɹ ət list ə mɝtʃəns ɡɑɹd," mæt wɛn ɑn wɪð ə ɡɹɪn ðət simd oʊnli ə lɪɾəl fɔɹst. hi hɛftəɾ ɪz baʊ. "æn ɑnəs mænz wɛpən ɪzənt ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ hɪm."

For the first time Mat noticed the sword at Rand's waist, and pointed to it. "You becoming a Warder?" He laughed, then swallowed it with a quick glance at Lan. The Warder apparently took no notice. "Or at least a merchant's guard," Mat went on with a grin that seemed only a little forced. He hefted his bow. "An honest man's weapon isn't good enough for him."

ɹænd θɔɾ əbaʊt flɝɪʃɪŋ ðə sɔɹd, bʌt læn biɪŋ ðəɹ stɑp hɪm. ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz nɑɾ ivən lʊkɪŋ ɪn ɪz dɝɛkʃən, bʌɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ ðə mæn wɑz əwɛɹ ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət wɛn ɑn ɝaʊn hɪm. ɪnstɛɾ i sɛd wɪð ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd kæʒəɑlnəs, "ɪt maɪt bi jusfəl," əz ɪf wɛɹɪŋ ə sɔɹd wɝ nʌθɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi.

Rand thought about flourishing the sword, but Lan being there stopped him. The Warder was not even looking in his direction, but he was sure the man was aware of everything that went on around him. Instead he said with exaggerated casualness, "It might be useful," as if wearing a sword were nothing out of the ordinary.

pɛɹɪn muvd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪd sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz kloʊk. ɹænd ɡlɪmpst ə waɪd lɛðɝ bɛlt ɛnsɝkəlɪŋ ði əpɹɛntəs blæksmɪθs weɪst, wɪð ðə hændəl ʌv ən æks θɹʌs θɹu ə lup ɑn ðə bɛlt.

Perrin moved, trying to hide something under his cloak. Rand glimpsed a wide leather belt encircling the apprentice blacksmith's waist, with the handle of an axe thrust through a loop on the belt.

"wʌt juv ðɛɹ?" hi æskt.

"What do you have there?" he asked.

"mɝtʃəns ɡɑɹd, ɪndid," mæt huɾɪd.

"Merchant's guard, indeed," Mat hooted.

ðə ʃæɡi-hɛɹd juθ ɡeɪv mæt ə fɹaʊn ðət sədʒɛstəɾ i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi hæd mɔɹ ðən ɪz fɛɹ ʃɛɹ ə dʒoʊkɪŋ, ðən saɪd hɛvəli ən tɔs bæk ɪz kloʊk tə ənkʌvɝ ði æks. ɪt wɑz noʊ kɑmən wʊdzmənz tul. ə bɹɔd hæf-mun bleɪɾ ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ə ðə hɛɾ ən ə kɝv spaɪk ɑn ði ʌðɝ meɪɾ ɪɾ ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz stʃɹeɪnʒ fəɹ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz əz ɹændz sɔɹd. pɛɹɪnz hæn ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ɪt wɪð ə sɛns ə fəmɪljɛɹəɾi, ðoʊ.

The shaggy-haired youth gave Mat a frown that suggested he had already had more than his fair share of joking, then sighed heavily and tossed back his cloak to uncover the axe. It was no common woodsman's tool. A broad half-moon blade on one side of the head and a curved spike on the other made it every bit as strange for the Two Rivers as Rand's sword. Perrin's hand rested on it with a sense of familiarity, though.

"mæstɝ luhən meɪɾ ɪɾ əbaʊt tu jɪɹz əɡoʊ, fəɹ ə wʊl-baɪɝz ɡɑɹd. bʌt wən ɪt wɑz dʌn ðə fɛloʊ wʊdn peɪ wʌɾ i hæɾ əɡɹid, ən mæstɝ luhən wəd nɑt teɪk lɛs. hi ɡeɪv ɪt tə mi wɛn" - hi klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt, ðən ʃɑt ɹænd ðə seɪm wɔɹnɪŋ fɹaʊn hid ɡɪvən mæt - "wɛn i faʊn mi pɹæktəsɪŋ wɪð ɪt. hi sɛɾ aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl əv ɪt sɪns i kʊdn meɪk ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl fɹəm ɪt."

"Master Luhhan made it about two years ago, for a wool-buyer's guard. But when it was done the fellow wouldn't pay what he had agreed, and Master Luhhan would not take less. He gave it to me when" - he cleared his throat, then shot Rand the same warning frown he'd given Mat - "when he found me practicing with it. He said I might as well have it since he couldn't make anything useful from it."

"pɹæktəsɪŋ," mæt snɪkɝd, bʌt hɛld ʌp ɪz hænz suðɪŋli wən pɛɹɪn ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛd. "æz jə seɪ. ɪts dʒʌst əz wɛl wʌn ʌv əs noʊz haʊ tə juz ə ɹil wɛpən."

"Practicing," Mat snickered, but held up his hands soothingly when Perrin raised his head. "As you say. It's just as well one of us knows how to use a real weapon."

"ðæt baʊ ɪz ə ɹil wɛpən," læn sɛd sʌɾənli. hi pɹɑpt ən ɑɹm əkɹɔs ðə sæɾəl ə hɪz tɔl blæk ən ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əm ɡɹeɪvli. "soʊ ɑɹ ðə slɪŋz aɪv sin jə vɪlədʒ bɔɪz wɪð. dʒʌs kəz jə nɛvɝ juzd əm fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt hʌntɪŋ ɹæbəts əɹ tʃeɪsɪŋ ə wʊlf əweɪ fɹəm ðə ʃip meɪks noʊ dɪfɝəns. ɛniθɪŋ kən bi ə wɛpən, ɪf ðə mæn əɹ wʊmən u hoʊlz ɪts ðə nɝv ən wɪl tə meɪk ɪt soʊ. tʃɹɑləks əsaɪd, jə hæd bɛɾɝ əv ðət klɪɹ ɪn jəɹ maɪnz bɪfɔɹ wi liv ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, bɪfɔɹ wi liv ɛmənz fild, ɪf jə wɑnə ɹitʃ tɑɹ vəlɑn əlaɪv."

"That bow is a real weapon," Lan said suddenly. He propped an arm across the saddle of his tall black and regarded them gravely. "So are the slings I've seen you village boys with. Just because you never used them for anything but hunting rabbits or chasing a wolf away from the sheep makes no difference. Anything can be a weapon, if the man or woman who holds it has the nerve and will to make it so. Trollocs aside, you had better have that clear in your minds before we leave the Two Rivers, before we leave Emond's Field, if you want to reach Tar Valon alive."

hɪz feɪs ən vɔɪs, koʊld əz dɛθ ən hɑɹɾ əz ə ɹʌf-hjun ɡɹeɪvstoʊn, staɪfəl ðɛɹ smaɪlz ən ðɛɹ tʌŋz. pɛɹɪn ɡɹɪməst ən pʊld ɪz kloʊk bæk oʊvɝ ði æks. mæt stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪz fiɾ ən stɝd ðə stʃɹɔ ɑn ðə steɪbəl flɔɹ wɪð ɪz toʊ. ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɡɹʌntɪɾ ən wɛn bæk tə hɪz tʃɛkɪŋ, ən ðə saɪləns lɛŋθənd.

His face and voice, cold as death and hard as a rough-hewn gravestone, stifled their smiles and their tongues. Perrin grimaced and pulled his cloak back over the axe. Mat stared at his feet and stirred the straw on the stable floor with his toe. The Warder grunted and went back to his checking, and the silence lengthened.

"ɪɾ ɪzən mʌtʃ laɪk ðə stɔɹiz," mæt sɛd, faɪnəli.

"It isn't much like the stories," Mat said, finally.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd saʊɝli. "tʃɹɑləks, ə wɔɹɾɝ, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. wʌt mɔɹ kəd jə æsk?"

"I don't know," Perrin said sourly. "Trollocs, a Warder, an Aes Sedai. What more could you ask?"

"ɛɛs sədaɪ," mæt wɪspɝd, saʊndɪŋ əz ɪf i wɝ sʌɾənli koʊld.

"Aes Sedai," Mat whispered, sounding as if he were suddenly cold.

"du jə bɪliv hɝ, ɹænd?" pɛɹɪn æskt. "aɪ min, wʌt wəd tʃɹɑləks wɑnt wɪð ʌs?"

"Do you believe her, Rand?" Perrin asked. "I mean, what would Trollocs want with us?"

əz wʌn, ðeɪ ɡlænst ət ðə wɔɹɾɝ. læn əpɪɹɾ əbzɔɹbd ɪn ðə waɪt mɛɹz sæɾəl ɡɝθ, bʌt ðə θɹi ʌv əm muv bæk təwɔɹd ðə steɪbəl dɔɹ, əweɪ fɹəm læn. ivən soʊ, ðeɪ hʌɾəld təɡɛðɝ ən spoʊk sɔfli.

As one, they glanced at the Warder. Lan appeared absorbed in the white mare's saddle girth, but the three of them moved back toward the stable door, away from Lan. Even so, they huddled together and spoke softly.

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ, bʌt ʃi hæɾ ɪt ɹaɪɾ əbaʊɾ əɹ fɑɹmz biɪŋ ði oʊnli wʌnz ətækt. ən ðeɪ ətæk mæstɝ luhənz haʊs ən ðə fɔɹdʒ fɝst, hɪɹ ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ. aɪ æsk ðə meɪɝ. ɪts əz izi tə bɪliv ðeɪ ɑɹ æftɝ əs əz ɛniθɪŋ ɛls aɪ kən θɪŋk ʌv." sʌɾənli hi ɹilaɪz ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm.

Rand shook his head. "I don't know, but she had it right about our farms being the only ones attacked. And they attacked Master Luhhan's house and the forge first, here in the village. I asked the Mayor. It's as easy to believe they are after us as anything else I can think of." Suddenly he realized they were both staring at him.

"ju æsk ðə meɪɝ?" mæt sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "ʃi sɛd nɑt tə tɛl ɛnibəɾi."

"You asked the Mayor?" Mat said incredulously. "She said not to tell anybody."

"aɪ dɪdn tɛl ɪm waɪ aɪ wɑz æskɪŋ," ɹænd pɹətɛstəd. "du jə min jə dɪdn tɔk tə ɛnibəɾi əɾ ɔl? jə dɪdn lɛɾ ɛnibəɾi noʊ jəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ?"

"I didn't tell him why I was asking," Rand protested. "Do you mean you didn't talk to anybody at all? You didn't let anybody know you're going?"

pɛɹɪn ʃɹʌɡd dɪfɛnsɪvli. "mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛd nɑɾ ɛnibəɾi."

Perrin shrugged defensively. "Moiraine Sedai said not anybody."

"wi lɛf noʊts," mæt sɛd. "fɔɹ əɹ fæmliz. ðəl faɪn əm ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. ɹænd, maɪ mʌðɝ θɪŋks tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪz ðə nɛks θɪŋ tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl." hi ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl læf tə ʃoʊ hi dɪd nɑt ʃɛɹ əɹ əpɪnjən. ɪt wɑz nɑt vɛɹi kənvɪnsɪŋ. "ʃid tʃɹaɪ tə lɑk mi ɪn ðə sɛlɝ ɪf ʃi bɪlivd aɪ wɑz ivən θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ ðɛɹ."

"We left notes," Mat said. "For our families. They'll find them in the morning. Rand, my mother thinks Tar Valon is the next thing to Shayol Ghul." He gave a little laugh to show he did not share her opinion. It was not very convincing. "She'd try to lock me in the cellar if she believed I was even thinking of going there."

"mæstɝ luhən ɪz stʌbɝn əz stoʊn," pɛɹɪn æɾəd, "æn mɪstʃɹəs luhən ɪz wɝs. ɪf jud sin əɹ dɪɡɪŋ θɹu wʌts lɛft ə ðə haʊs, seɪɪŋ ʃi hoʊp ðə tʃɹɑləks dɪd kʌm bæk soʊ ʃi kəd ɡɛɾ əɹ hænz ɑn ðɛm. . . ."

"Master Luhhan is stubborn as stone," Perrin added, "and Mistress Luhhan is worse. If you'd seen her digging through what's left of the house, saying she hoped the Trollocs did come back so she could get her hands on them. . . ."

"bɝn mi, ɹænd," mæt sɛd, "aɪ noʊ ʃiz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɔl, bʌt ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ ɹɪli hɪɹ. ʃi sɛd nɑt tə tɛl ɛnibəɾi. ɪf ən ɛɛs sədaɪ dʌznt noʊ wʌt tə də əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðɪs, hu dʌz?"

"Burn me, Rand," Mat said, "I know she's an Aes Sedai and all, but the Trollocs were really here. She said not to tell anybody. If an Aes Sedai doesn't know what to do about something like this, who does?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ." ɹænd ɹʌbd əɾ ɪz fɔɹhɛd. hɪz hɛd hɝt; hi kəd nɑt ɡɛt ðət dʒɹim aʊɾ ə hɪz maɪnd. "maɪ fɑðɝ bɪlivz hɝ. ət list, hi əɡɹid ðət wi hæd tə ɡoʊ."

"I don't know." Rand rubbed at his forehead. His head hurt; he could not get that dream out of his mind. "My father believes her. At least, he agreed that we had to go."

sʌɾənli mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ. "ju tɔk tə jəɹ fɑðɝ əbaʊt ðɪs dʒɝni?" ʃi wɑz kloʊðd ɪn dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ fɹəm hɛd tə fʊt, wɪð ə skɝt dɪvaɪɾəd fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ əstʃɹaɪd, ən ðə sɝpən ɹɪŋ wɑz ði oʊnli ɡoʊld ʃi wɔɹ naʊ.

Suddenly Moiraine was in the doorway. "You talked to your father about this journey?" She was clothed in dark gray from head to foot, with a skirt divided for riding astride, and the serpent ring was the only gold she wore now.

ɹænd aɪɾ əɹ wɔkɪŋ stæf; dɪspaɪt ðə fleɪmz i hæd sin, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ə tʃæɹɪŋ, əɹ ivən sʊt. "aɪ kʊdnt ɡoʊ ɔf wɪθaʊt lɛɾɪŋ ɪm noʊ."

Rand eyed her walking staff; despite the flames he had seen, there was no sign of charring, or even soot. "I couldn't go off without letting him know."

ʃi aɪɾ ɪm fəɹ ə moʊmənt wɪð pɝs lɪps bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ tə ði ʌðɝz. "æn dɪd jə ɔlsoʊ dɪsaɪd ðəɾ ə noʊt wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf?" mæt ən pɛɹɪn tɔkt ɑn tɑp ʌv itʃ ʌðɝ, əʃʊɹɪŋ əɹ ðeɪ hæɾ oʊnli lɛf noʊts, ðə weɪ ʃi hæd sɛd. nɑɾɪŋ, ʃi weɪvd əm tə saɪləns, ən ɡeɪv ɹænd ə ʃɑɹp lʊk. "wʌɾ ɪz dʌn ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi woʊvən ɪn ðə pæɾɝn. læn?"

She eyed him for a moment with pursed lips before turning to the others. "And did you also decide that a note was not enough?" Mat and Perrin talked on top of each other, assuring her they had only left notes, the way she had said. Nodding, she waved them to silence, and gave Rand a sharp look. "What is done is already woven in the Pattern. Lan?"

"ðə hɔɹsəz ɑɹ ɹɛɾi," ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd, "ænd wɪv ɪnʌf pɹəvɪʒənz tə ɹitʃ bɛɹlən wɪð səm tə spɛɹ. wi kən liv əɾ ɛni taɪm. aɪ sədʒɛs naʊ."

"The horses are ready," the Warder said, "and we have enough provisions to reach Baerlon with some to spare. We can leave at any time. I suggest now."

"nɑt wɪθaʊt mi." ɛɡwin slɪpt ɪndə ðə steɪbəl, ə ʃɔl-ɹæp bʌndəl ɪn əɹ ɑɹmz. ɹænd nɪɹli fɛl oʊvɝ ɪz oʊn fit.

"Not without me." Egwene slipped into the stable, a shawl-wrapped bundle in her arms. Rand nearly fell over his own feet.

lænz sɔɹd hæd kʌm hæf aʊɾ ʌv ɪts ʃiθ; wən i sɔ hu ɪt wɑz i ʃʌv ðə bleɪd bæk, hɪz aɪz sʌɾənli flæt. pɛɹɪn ən mæt bɪɡæn bæbəlɪŋ tə kənvɪns mɔɪɹeɪn ðeɪ hæd nɑt toʊld ɛɡwin əbaʊt livɪŋ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛm; ʃi sɪmpli lʊkt əɾ ɛɡwin, tæpɪŋ əɹ lɪps θɔtfəli wɪð wʌn fɪŋɡɝ.

Lan's sword had come half out of its sheath; when he saw who it was he shoved the blade back, his eyes suddenly flat. Perrin and Mat began babbling to convince Moiraine they had not told Egwene about leaving. The Aes Sedai ignored them; she simply looked at Egwene, tapping her lips thoughtfully with one finger.

ðə hʊɾ ʌv ɛɡwinz dɑɹk bɹaʊn kloʊk wɑz pʊld ʌp, bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə haɪd ðə dɪfaɪənt weɪ ʃi feɪs mɔɪɹeɪn. "aɪ hæv ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ nid hɪɹ. ɪnkluɾɪŋ fud. ən əl nɑt bi lɛf bɪhaɪnd. əl pɹɑbli nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ ənʌðɝ tʃæns tə si ðə wɝld aʊtsaɪd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz."

The hood of Egwene's dark brown cloak was pulled up, but not enough to hide the defiant way she faced Moiraine. "I have everything I need here. Including food. And I will not be left behind. I'll probably never get another chance to see the world outside the Two Rivers."

"ðɪs ɪzən ə pɪknɪk tʃɹɪp ɪndə ðə wɔɾɝwʊd, ɛɡwin," mæt ɡɹaʊld. hi stɛp bæk wən ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɪm fɹəm ʌndɝ loʊɝd bɹaʊz.

"This isn't a picnic trip into the Waterwood, Egwene," Mat growled. He stepped back when she looked at him from under lowered brows.

"θæŋk ju, mæt. aɪ wʊdn əv noʊn. dʒju θɪŋk jə θɹi ɑɹ ði oʊnli wʌnz u wɑnə si wʌts aʊtsaɪd? aɪv dʒɹimd əbaʊɾ ɪɾ əz lɔŋ əz jə hæv, ən aɪ doʊn ɪntɛn tə mɪs ðɪs tʃæns."

"Thank you, Mat. I wouldn't have known. Do you think you three are the only ones who want to see what's outside? I've dreamed about it as long as you have, and I don't intend to miss this chance."

"haʊ dɪd jə faɪn aʊt wi wɝ livɪŋ?" ɹænd dɪmændəd. "ɛniweɪ, jə kænt ɡoʊ wɪð ʌs. wi ɑɹən livɪŋ fəɹ ðə fʌn ʌv ɪt. ðə tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ æftɝ ʌs." ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə tɑlɝən lʊk, ən i flʌʃt ən stɪfən ɪndɪɡnənli.

"How did you find out we were leaving?" Rand demanded. "Anyway, you can't go with us. We aren't leaving for the fun of it. The Trollocs are after us." She gave him a tolerant look, and he flushed and stiffened indignantly.

"fɝst," ʃi toʊld ɪm peɪʃənli, "aɪ sɔ mæt kɹipɪŋ əbaʊt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ hɑɹd nɑt tə bi noʊɾəst. ðən aɪ sɔ pɛɹɪn ətɛmptɪŋ tə haɪd ðəɾ əbsɝd ɡɹeɪɾ æks ʌndɝ ɪz kloʊk. aɪ nu læn hæd bɑɾ ə hɔɹs, ən ɪt sʌɾənli əkɝd tə mi tə wʌndɝ waɪ hi niɾəd ənʌðɝ. ən ɪf i kəd baɪ wʌn, hi kəd baɪ ʌðɝz. pʊɾɪŋ ðət wɪð mæt ən pɛɹɪn snikɪŋ əbaʊt laɪk bʊl kævz pɹitɛndɪŋ tə bi fɑksəz . . . wɛl, aɪ kəd si oʊnli wʌn ænsɝ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf aɪm sɝpɹaɪzd əɹ nɑt tə faɪn jə hɪɹ, ɹænd, æftɝ ɔl jəɹ tɔk əbaʊt deɪdʒɹimz. wɪð mæt ən pɛɹɪn ɪnvɑlvd, aɪ səpoʊz aɪ ʃʊɾə noʊn jə wəd bi ɪn ɪt, tu."

"First," she told him patiently, "I saw Mat creeping about, trying hard not to be noticed. Then I saw Perrin attempting to hide that absurd great axe under his cloak. I knew Lan had bought a horse, and it suddenly occurred to me to wonder why he needed another. And if he could buy one, he could buy others. Putting that with Mat and Perrin sneaking about like bull calves pretending to be foxes . . . well, I could see only one answer. I don't know if I'm surprised or not to find you here, Rand, after all your talk about daydreams. With Mat and Perrin involved, I suppose I should have known you would be in it, too."

"aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ, ɛɡwin," ɹænd sɛd. "ɔl ʌv əs du, əɹ ðə tʃɹɑləks wɪl kʌm bæk."

"I have to go, Egwene," Rand said. "All of us do, or the Trollocs will come back."

"ðə tʃɹɑləks!" ɛɡwin læft ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "ɹænd, ɪf juv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə si səm ə ðə wɝld, wɛl ən ɡʊd, bʌt pliz spɛɹ mi ɛni ʌv jəɹ nɑnsɛnsɪkəl teɪlz."

"The Trollocs!" Egwene laughed incredulously. "Rand, if you've decided to see some of the world, well and good, but please spare me any of your nonsensical tales."

"ɪts tʃɹu," pɛɹɪn sɛɾ əz mæt bɪɡæn, "ðə tʃɹɑləks - "

"It's true," Perrin said as Mat began, "The Trollocs - "

"ɪnʌf," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd kwaɪətli, bʌɾ ɪt kʌt ðɛɹ tɔk əz ʃɑɹpli əz ə naɪf. "dɪɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls noʊɾəs ɔl ə ðɪs?" hɝ vɔɪs wɑz sɑft, bʌɾ ɛɡwin swɑloʊɾ ən dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp bɪfɔɹ ænsɝɪŋ.

"Enough," Moiraine said quietly, but it cut their talk as sharply as a knife. "Did anyone else notice all of this?" Her voice was soft, but Egwene swallowed and drew herself up before answering.

"æftɝ læs naɪt, ɔl ðeɪ kən θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪz ɹibɪldɪŋ, ðəɾ ən wʌt tə də ɪf ɪt hæpənz əɡɛn. ðeɪ kʊdn si ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ənlɛs ɪt wɑz pʊʃt ʌndɝ ðɛɹ noʊzɪz. ən aɪ toʊl noʊ wʌn wʌɾ aɪ səspɛktəd. noʊ wʌn."

"After last night, all they can think about is rebuilding, that and what to do if it happens again. They couldn't see anything else unless it was pushed under their noses. And I told no one what I suspected. No one."

"vɛɹi wɛl," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt. "ju meɪ kʌm wɪð ʌs."

"Very well," Moiraine said after a moment. "You may come with us."

ə stɑɹɾəld ɪkspɹɛʃən dɑɹɾɪd əkɹɔs lænz feɪs. ɪt wɑz ɡɔn ɪn ən ɪnstənt, livɪŋ ɪm aʊtwɝdli kɑm, bʌt fjʊɹiəs wɝdz ɪɹʌptəd fɹəm hɪm. "noʊ, mɔɪɹeɪn!"

A startled expression darted across Lan's face. It was gone in an instant, leaving him outwardly calm, but furious words erupted from him. "No, Moiraine!"

"ɪɾ ɪz pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn, naʊ, læn."

"It is part of the Pattern, now, Lan."

"ɪɾ ɪz ɹɪdɪkjələs!" hi ɹitɔɹɾɪd. "ðɛɹz noʊ ɹizən fəɹ əɹ tə kʌm əlɔŋ, ən ɛvɹi ɹizən fəɹ əɹ nɑt tə."

"It is ridiculous!" he retorted. "There's no reason for her to come along, and every reason for her not to."

"ðɛɹ ɪz ə ɹizən fəɹ ɪt," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd kɑmli. "ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn, læn." ðə wɔɹɾɝz stoʊni feɪs ʃoʊd nʌθɪŋ, bʌɾ i nɑɾəd sloʊli.

"There is a reason for it," Moiraine said calmly. "A part of the Pattern, Lan." The Warder's stony face showed nothing, but he nodded slowly.

"bʌt, ɛɡwin," ɹænd sɛd, "ðə tʃɹɑləks wɪl bi tʃeɪsɪŋ ʌs. wi woʊn bi seɪf əntɪl wi ɡɛt tə tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"But, Egwene," Rand said, "the Trollocs will be chasing us. We won't be safe until we get to Tar Valon."

"doʊn tʃɹaɪ tə fɹaɪɾən mi ɔf," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ æm ɡoʊɪŋ."

"Don't try to frighten me off," she said. "I am going."

ɹænd nu ðət toʊn ə vɔɪs. hi hæd nɑt hɝɾ ɪt sɪns ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd ðət klaɪmɪŋ ðə tɔlɪs tʃɹiz wɑz fəɹ tʃɪlʒɹən, bʌɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪt wɛl. "ɪf jə θɪŋk biɪŋ tʃeɪs baɪ tʃɹɑləks wɪl bi fʌn," hi bɪɡæn, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn ɪntɝʌptɪd.

Rand knew that tone of voice. He had not heard it since she decided that climbing the tallest trees was for children, but he remembered it well. "If you think being chased by Trollocs will be fun," he began, but Moiraine interrupted.

"wi hæv noʊ taɪm fəɹ ðɪs. wi mʌs bi əz fɑɹ əweɪ əz pɑsəbəl baɪ deɪbɹeɪk. ɪf ʃiz lɛf bɪhaɪnd, ɹænd, ʃi kəd ɹaʊs ðə vɪlədʒ bɪfɔɹ wɪv ɡɔn ə maɪl, ən ðət wəd ʃʊɹli wɔɹn ðə mɹdʒɹɑl."

"We have no time for this. We must be as far away as possible by daybreak. If she is left behind, Rand, she could rouse the village before we have gone a mile, and that would surely warn the Myrddraal."

"aɪ wəd nɑt də ðæt," ɛɡwin pɹətɛstəd.

"I would not do that," Egwene protested.

"ʃi kən ɹaɪd ðə ɡlimənz hɔɹs," ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd. "aɪl liv ɪm ɪnʌf tə baɪ ənʌðɝ."

"She can ride the gleeman's horse," the Warder said. "I'll leave him enough to buy another."

"ðæt wɪl nɑt bi pɑsəbəl," keɪm tɑm mɛɹɪlɪnz ɹɛzənən vɔɪs fɹəm ðə heɪlɔft. lænz sɔɹd lɛft ɪts ʃiθ ðɪs taɪm, ən i dɪd nɑt pʊɾ ɪt bæk əz i stɛɹɾ ʌp ət ðə ɡlimən.

"That will not be possible," came Thom Merrilin's resonant voice from the hayloft. Lan's sword left its sheath this time, and he did not put it back as he stared up at the gleeman.

tɑm tɔs daʊn ə blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl, ðən slʌŋ ɪz keɪs fluɾ ən hɑɹp əkɹɔs ɪz bæk ən ʃoʊldɝd bʌlʒɪŋ sæɾəlbæɡz. "ðɪs vɪlədʒ əz noʊ jus fəɹ mi, naʊ, waɪl ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, aɪ hæv nɛvɝ pɝfɔɹmd ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. ən ðoʊ aɪ juʒəwəli dʒɝni əloʊn, æftɝ læs naɪɾ aɪ hæv noʊ əbdʒɛkʃənz əɾ ɔl tə tʃɹævlɪŋ ɪn kʌmpəni."

Thom tossed down a blanketroll, then slung his cased flute and harp across his back and shouldered bulging saddlebags. "This village has no use for me, now, while on the other hand, I have never performed in Tar Valon. And though I usually journey alone, after last night I have no objections at all to traveling in company."

ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɡeɪv pɛɹɪn ə hɑɹd lʊk, ən pɛɹɪn ʃɪftəɾ ənkʌmftəbli. "aɪ dɪdn θɪŋk ə lʊkɪŋ ɪn ðə lɔft," hi mʌɾɝd.

The Warder gave Perrin a hard look, and Perrin shifted uncomfortably. "I didn't think of looking in the loft," he muttered.

əz ðə lɔŋ-lɪmd ɡlimən skɹæmbəl daʊn ðə læɾɝ fɹəm ðə lɔft, læn spoʊk, stɪfli fɔɹməl. "ɪz ðɪs pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn, tu, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ?"

As the long-limbed gleeman scrambled down the ladder from the loft, Lan spoke, stiffly formal. "Is this part of the Pattern, too, Moiraine Sedai?"

"ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪz ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn, maɪ oʊl fɹɛnd," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd sɔfli. "wi kænɑt pɪk ən tʃuz. bʌt wi ʃæl si."

"Everything is a part of the Pattern, my old friend," Moiraine replied softly. "We cannot pick and choose. But we shall see."

tɑm pʊɾ ɪz fiɾ ɑn ðə steɪbəl flɔɹ ən tɝn fɹəm ðə læɾɝ, bɹʌʃɪŋ stʃɹɔ fɹəm ɪz pætʃ-kʌvɝd kloʊk. "ɪn fækt," hi sɛɾ ɪn mɔɹ nɔɹməl toʊnz, "ju maɪt seɪ ðəɾ aɪ ɪnsɪst ɑn tʃɹævlɪŋ ɪn kʌmpəni. aɪ hæv ɡɪvən mɛni aʊɝz oʊvɝ mɛni mʌɡz ʌv eɪl tə θɪŋkɪŋ ə haʊ aɪ maɪɾ ɛn maɪ deɪz. eɪ tʃɹɑlɑks kʊkpɑt wɑz nɑt wʌn ə ðə θɔts." hi lʊkt əskæns ət ðə wɔɹɾɝz sɔɹd. "ðɛɹz noʊ nid fəɹ ðæt. aɪm nɑɾ ə tʃiz fəɹ slaɪsɪŋ."

Thom put his feet on the stable floor and turned from the ladder, brushing straw from his patch-covered cloak. "In fact," he said in more normal tones, "you might say that I insist on traveling in company. I have given many hours over many mugs of ale to thinking of how I might end my days. A Trolloc's cookpot was not one of the thoughts." He looked askance at the Warder's sword. "There's no need for that. I am not a cheese for slicing."

"mæstɝ mɛɹɪlɪn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "wi mʌst ɡoʊ kwɪkli, ən ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli ɪn ɡɹeɪt deɪnʒɝ. ðə tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ stɪl aʊt ðɛɹ, ən wi ɡoʊ baɪ naɪt. ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ ðət jə wɑnə tʃɹævəl wɪð ʌs?"

"Master Merrilin," Moiraine said, "we must go quickly, and almost certainly in great danger. The Trollocs are still out there, and we go by night. Are you sure that you want to travel with us?"

tɑm aɪd ðə lɑɾ ə ðɛm wɪð ə kwɪtsɪkəl smaɪl. "ɪf ɪts nɑt tu deɪnʒɝəs fəɹ ðə ɡɝl, ɪt kæn bi tu deɪnʒɝəs fəɹ mi. bɪsaɪdz, wʌt ɡlimən wəd nɑt feɪs ə lɪɾəl deɪnʒɝ tə pɝfɔɹm ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn?"

Thom eyed the lot of them with a quizzical smile. "If it is not too dangerous for the girl, it can't be too dangerous for me. Besides, what gleeman would not face a little danger to perform in Tar Valon?"

mɔɪɹeɪn nɑɾəd, ən læn skæbɑɹɾɪd ɪz sɔɹd. ɹænd sʌɾənli wʌndɝd wʌt wʊɾə hæpən ɪf tɑm hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪz maɪnd, əɹ ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn hæd nɑt nɑɾəd. ðə ɡlimən bɪɡæn sæɾəlɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs əz ɪf sɪməlɝ θɔts hæd nɛvɝ kɹɔst ɪz maɪnd, bʌt ɹænd noʊɾəst ðəɾ i aɪd lænz sɔɹd mɔɹ ðən wʌns.

Moiraine nodded, and Lan scabbarded his sword. Rand suddenly wondered what would have happened if Thom had changed his mind, or if Moiraine had not nodded. The gleeman began saddling his horse as if similar thoughts had never crossed his mind, but Rand noticed that he eyed Lan's sword more than once.

"naʊ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "wʌt hɔɹs fəɹ ɛɡwin?"

"Now," Moiraine said. "What horse for Egwene?"

"ðə pɛdlɝz hɔɹsəz ɑɹ əz bæɾ əz ðə dɝənz," ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɹɪplaɪd saʊɝli. "stʃɹɔŋ, bʌt sloʊ plɑɾɝz."

"The peddler's horses are as bad as the Dhurrans," the Warder replied sourly. "Strong, but slow plodders."

"bɛlə," ɹænd sɛd, ɡɛɾɪŋ ə lʊk fɹəm læn ðət meɪɾ ɪm wɪʃ i hæd kɛp saɪlənt. bʌɾ i nu hi kəd nɑt dɪsweɪɾ ɛɡwin; ði oʊnli θɪŋ lɛft wɑz tə hɛlp. "bɛlə meɪ nɑt bi əz fæst əz ði ʌðɝz, bʌt ʃiz stʃɹɔŋ. aɪ ɹaɪɾ əɹ səmtaɪmz. ʃi kən kip ʌp."

"Bela," Rand said, getting a look from Lan that made him wish he had kept silent. But he knew he could not dissuade Egwene; the only thing left was to help. "Bela may not be as fast as the others, but she's strong. I ride her sometimes. She can keep up."

læn lʊkt ɪndə bɛləz stɔl, mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. "ʃi maɪt bi ə lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ ðən ði ʌðɝz," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "aɪ doʊn səpoʊz ðəɹ ɪz ɛni ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs."

Lan looked into Bela's stall, muttering under his breath. "She might be a little better than the others," he said finally. "I don't suppose there is any other choice."

"ðɛn ʃɪl əv tə du," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ɹænd, faɪn ə sæɾəl fəɹ bɛlə. kwɪkli, naʊ! wɪv tɑɹid tu lɔŋ ɔlɹɛɾi."

"Then she will have to do," Moiraine said. "Rand, find a saddle for Bela. Quickly, now! We have tarried too long already."

ɹænd hɝidli tʃoʊz ə sæɾəl ən blæŋkəɾ ɪn ðə tæk ɹum, ðən fɛtʃt bɛlə fɹəm əɹ stɔl. ðə mɛɹ lʊk bæk əɾ ɪm ɪn slipi sɝpɹaɪz wən i pʊt ðə sæɾəl ɑn əɹ bæk. wən i ɹoʊd hɝ, ɪt wɑz bæɹbækt; ʃi wɑz nɑt juz tə ə sæɾəl. hi meɪd suðɪŋ nɔɪzɪz waɪl i taɪɾənd ðə ɡɝθ stʃɹæp, ən ʃi æksɛptɪd ði ɑɾəti wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə ʃeɪk ə hɝ meɪn.

Rand hurriedly chose a saddle and blanket in the tack room, then fetched Bela from her stall. The mare looked back at him in sleepy surprise when he put the saddle on her back. When he rode her, it was barebacked; she was not used to a saddle. He made soothing noises while he tightened the girth strap, and she accepted the oddity with no more than a shake of her mane.

teɪkɪŋ ɛɡwinz bʌndəl fɹəm hɝ, hi taɪɾ ɪɾ ɑn bɪhaɪn ðə sæɾəl waɪl ʃi maʊntəɾ ən ədʒʌstəɾ əɹ skɝts. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt dɪvaɪɾəd fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ əstʃɹaɪd, soʊ hɝ wʊl stɑkɪŋz wɝ bɛɹd tə ðə ni. ʃi wɔɹ ðə seɪm sɑf lɛðɝ ʃuz əz ɔl ði ʌðɝ vɪlədʒ ɡɝlz. ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ əɾ ɔl suɾəd fəɹ dʒɝniɪŋ tə wɑtʃ hɪl, mʌtʃ lɛs tɑɹ vəlɑn.

Taking Egwene's bundle from her, he tied it on behind the saddle while she mounted and adjusted her skirts. They were not divided for riding astride, so her wool stockings were bared to the knee. She wore the same soft leather shoes as all the other village girls. They were not at all suited for journeying to Watch Hill, much less Tar Valon.

"aɪ stɪl θɪŋk jə ʃʊdn kʌm," hi sɛd. "aɪ wɑzn meɪkɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp əbaʊt ðə tʃɹɑləks. bʌɾ aɪ pɹɑməs əl teɪk kɛɹ ə ju."

"I still think you shouldn't come," he said. "I wasn't making it up about the Trollocs. But I promise I will take care of you."

"pɝhæps əl teɪk kɛɹ ə ju," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd laɪtli. əɾ ɪz ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd lʊk ʃi smaɪld ən bɛn daʊn tə smuð ɪz hɛɹ. "aɪ noʊ jəl lʊk æftɝ mi, ɹænd. wɪl lʊk æftɝ itʃ ʌðɝ. bʌt naʊ jə hæd bɛɾɝ lʊk æftɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ ɑn jəɹ hɔɹs."

"Perhaps I'll take care of you," she replied lightly. At his exasperated look she smiled and bent down to smooth his hair. "I know you'll look after me, Rand. We will look after each other. But now you had better look after getting on your horse."

ɔl ə ði ʌðɝz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi maʊntəɾ ən weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ hɪm, hi ɹilaɪzd. ði oʊnli hɔɹs lɛft ɹaɪɾɝləs wɑz klaʊd, ə tɔl ɡɹeɪ wɪð ə blæk meɪn ən teɪl ðət bɪlɔŋ tə dʒɑn θeɪn, əɹ hæd. hi skɹæmbəld ɪndə ðə sæɾəl, ðoʊ nɑt wɪθaʊt dɪfəkəlti əz ðə ɡɹeɪ tɔst ɪz hɛɾ ən pɹænst saɪdweɪz əz ɹænd pʊɾ ɪz fʊɾ ɪn ðə stɝəp, ən ɪz skæbɝd kɑɾ ɪn ɪz lɛɡz. ɪt wɑz nɑt tʃæns ðəɾ ɪz fɹɛnz hæd nɑt tʃoʊzən klaʊd. mæstɝ θeɪn ɔfən ɹeɪs ðə spɪɹəɾəd ɡɹeɪ əɡɛns mɝtʃəns' hɔɹsəz, ən ɹænd hæd nɛvɝ noʊn ɪm tə luz, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ noʊn klaʊd tə ɡɪv ɛniwʌn ən izi ɹaɪd, iðɝ. læn mʌst əv ɡɪvən ə hjudʒ pɹaɪs tə meɪk ðə mɪlɝ sɛl. əz i sɛɾəld ɪn ðə sæɾəl klaʊdz dænsɪŋ ɪnkɹist, əz ɪf ðə ɡɹeɪ wɝ iɡɝ tə ɹʌn. ɹænd ɡɹɪp ðə ɹeɪnz fɝmli ən tʃɹaɪd tə θɪŋk ðəɾ i wəɾ əv noʊ tʃɹʌbəl. pɝhæps ɪf i kənvɪns hɪmsɛlf, hi kəd kənvɪns ðə hɔɹs, tu.

All of the others were already mounted and waiting for him, he realized. The only horse left riderless was Cloud, a tall gray with a black mane and tail that belonged to Jon Thane, or had. He scrambled into the saddle, though not without difficulty as the gray tossed his head and pranced sideways as Rand put his foot in the stirrup, and his scabbard caught in his legs. It was not chance that his friends had not chosen Cloud. Master Thane often raced the spirited gray against merchants' horses, and Rand had never known him to lose, but he had never known Cloud to give anyone an easy ride, either. Lan must have given a huge price to make the miller sell. As he settled in the saddle Cloud's dancing increased, as if the gray were eager to run. Rand gripped the reins firmly and tried to think that he would have no trouble. Perhaps if he convinced himself, he could convince the horse, too.

ən aʊl huɾɪd ɪn ðə naɪɾ aʊtsaɪd, ən ðə vɪlədʒ pipəl dʒʌmp bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ ɪt wɑz. ðeɪ læf nɝvəsli ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ʃeɪməfeɪs lʊks.

An owl hooted in the night outside, and the village people jumped before they realized what it was. They laughed nervously and exchanged shamefaced looks.

"nɛks θɪŋ, fil maɪs wɪl tʃeɪs əs ʌp ə tʃɹi," ɛɡwin sɛd wɪð ən ənstɛɾi tʃʌkəl.

"Next thing, field mice will chase us up a tree," Egwene said with an unsteady chuckle.

læn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "bɛɾɝ ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn wʊlvz."

Lan shook his head. "Better if it had been wolves."

"wʊlvz!" pɛɹɪn ɪkskleɪmd, ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ feɪvɝɾ ɪm wɪð ə flæt stɛɹ.

"Wolves!" Perrin exclaimed, and the Warder favored him with a flat stare.

"wʊlvz doʊn laɪk tʃɹɑləks, blæksmɪθ, ən tʃɹɑləks doʊn laɪk wʊlvz, əɹ dɑɡz, iðɝ. ɪf aɪ hɝd wʊlvz aɪ wəd bi ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɝ noʊ tʃɹɑləks weɪɾɪŋ aʊt ðəɹ fəɹ ʌs." hi muvd ɪndə ðə munlɪt naɪt, wɔkɪŋ ɪz tɔl blæk sloʊli.

"Wolves don't like Trollocs, blacksmith, and Trollocs don't like wolves, or dogs, either. If I heard wolves I would be sure there were no Trollocs waiting out there for us." He moved into the moonlit night, walking his tall black slowly.

mɔɪɹeɪn ɹoʊɾ æftɝ ɪm wɪθaʊɾ ə moʊməns hɛzəteɪʃən, ən ɛɡwin kɛp hɑɹd tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪz saɪd. ɹænd ən ðə ɡlimən bɹɔɾ ʌp ðə ɹɪɹ, fɑloʊɪŋ mæt ən pɛɹɪn.

Moiraine rode after him without a moment's hesitation, and Egwene kept hard to the Aes Sedai's side. Rand and the gleeman brought up the rear, following Mat and Perrin.

ðə bæk ə ði ɪn wɑz dɑɹk ən saɪlənt, ən dæpəl mun ʃædoʊz fɪl ðə steɪbliɑɹd. ðə sɑf θʌdz ə ðə hʊvz feɪɾəd kwɪkli, swɑloʊd baɪ ðə naɪt. ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs ðə wɔɹɾɝz kloʊk meɪɾ ɪm ə ʃædoʊ, tu. oʊnli ðə nid tə lɛɾ ɪm lɛd ðə weɪ kɛp ði ʌðɝz fɹəm klʌstɝɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm. ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə vɪlədʒ wɪθaʊt biɪŋ sin wɑz gɑnə bi noʊ izi tæsk, ɹænd dɪsaɪɾɪd əz i nɪɹd ðə ɡeɪt. ət list, wɪθaʊt biɪŋ sin baɪ vɪlɪdʒɝz. mɛni wɪndoʊz ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ ɪmɪɾəd peɪl jɛloʊ laɪt, ən ɔlðoʊ ðoʊz ɡloʊz sim vɛɹi smɔl ɪn ðə naɪt naʊ, ʃeɪps muv fɹikwənli wɪðɪn ðɛm, ðə ʃeɪps ə vɪlɪdʒɝz wɑtʃɪŋ tə si wʌt ðɪs naɪt bɹɔt. noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə bi kɑt baɪ sɝpɹaɪz əɡɛn.

The back of the inn was dark and silent, and dappled moon shadows filled the stableyard. The soft thuds of the hooves faded quickly, swallowed by the night. In the darkness the Warder's cloak made him a shadow, too. Only the need to let him lead the way kept the others from clustering around him. Getting out of the village without being seen was going to be no easy task, Rand decided as he neared the gate. At least, without being seen by villagers. Many windows in the village emitted pale yellow light, and although those glows seemed very small in the night now, shapes moved frequently within them, the shapes of villagers watching to see what this night brought. No one wanted to be caught by surprise again.

ɪn ðə dip ʃædoʊz bɪsaɪd ði ɪn, dʒʌst ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə livɪŋ ðə steɪbliɑɹd, læn əbɹʌpli hɔltəd, moʊʃənɪŋ ʃɑɹpli fəɹ saɪləns.

In the deep shadows beside the inn, just on the point of leaving the stableyard, Lan abruptly halted, motioning sharply for silence.

buts ɹæɾəld ɑn ðə wæɡən bɹɪdʒ, ən hɪɹ ən ðəɹ ɑn ðə bɹɪdʒ munlaɪt ɡlɪntɪɾ ɔf mɛɾəl. ðə buts klæɾɝd əkɹɔs ðə bɹɪdʒ, ɡɹeɪɾɪd ɑn ɡɹævəl, ən əpɹoʊtʃt ði ɪn. noʊ saʊn əɾ ɔl keɪm fɹəm ðoʊz ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ. ɹænd səspɛktəɾ ɪz fɹɛnz, ət list, wɝ tu fɹaɪɾənd tə meɪk ə nɔɪz. laɪk hɪm.

Boots rattled on the Wagon Bridge, and here and there on the bridge moonlight glinted off metal. The boots clattered across the bridge, grated on gravel, and approached the inn. No sound at all came from those in the shadow. Rand suspected his friends, at least, were too frightened to make a noise. Like him.

ðə fʊtstɛps hɔltəd bɪfɔɹ ði ɪn ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪnəs dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə dɪm laɪt fɹəm ðə kɑmən-ɹum wɪndoʊz. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əntɪl dʒɑn θeɪn stɛp fɔɹwɝd, ə spɪɹ pɹɑpt ɑn ɪz staʊt ʃoʊldɝ, ən oʊl dʒɝkɪn soʊn ɔl oʊvɝ wɪð stil dɪsks stʃɹeɪnɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst, ðət ɹænd sɔ ðɛm fəɹ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ. ə dʌzən mɛn fɹəm ðə vɪlədʒ ən ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ fɑɹmz, səm ɪn hɛlməts əɹ pisəz ʌv ɑɹmɝ ðət hæd leɪn dʌst-kʌvɝɾ ɪn æɾɪks fəɹ dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz, ɔl wɪð ə spɪɹ əɹ ə wʊdeɪks əɹ ə ɹʌsti bɪl.

The footsteps halted before the inn in the grayness just beyond the dim light from the common-room windows. It was not until Jon Thane stepped forward, a spear propped on his stout shoulder, an old jerkin sewn all over with steel disks straining across his chest, that Rand saw them for what they were. A dozen men from the village and the surrounding farms, some in helmets or pieces of armor that had lain dust-covered in attics for generations, all with a spear or a woodaxe or a rusty bill.

ðə mɪlɝ pɪɹɾ ɪndə ə kɑmən-ɹum wɪndoʊ, ðən tɝnd wɪð ə kɝt, "ɪt lʊks ɹaɪt hɪɹ." ði ʌðɝz fɔɹmd ɪn tu ɹæɡəd ɹæŋks bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən ðə pətʃɹoʊl mɑɹtʃt ɪndə ðə naɪɾ əz ɪf stɛpɪŋ tə θɹi dɪfɹən dʒɹʌmz.

The miller peered into a common-room window, then turned with a curt, "It looks right here." The others formed in two ragged ranks behind him, and the patrol marched into the night as if stepping to three different drums.

"tu dɑvɑl tʃɹɑləks wəɾ əv əm ɔl fəɹ bɹɛkfəst," læn mʌɾɝd wən ðə saʊn ə ðɛɹ buts hæd feɪɾəd, "bʌt ðeɪv aɪz ən ɪɹz." hi tɝn ɪz stæljən bæk. "kʌm."

"Two Dha'vol Trollocs would have them all for breakfast," Lan muttered when the sound of their boots had faded, "but they have eyes and ears." He turned his stallion back. "Come."

sloʊli, kwaɪətli, ðə wɔɹɾɝ tʊk əm bæk əkɹɔs ðə steɪbliɑɹd, daʊn ðə bæŋk θɹu ðə wɪloʊz ən ɪndə ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ wɔɾɝ. soʊ kloʊs tə ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪtsɛlf ðə koʊld, swɪft wɔɾɝ, ɡlimɪŋ əz ɪt swɝld ɝaʊn ðə hɔɹsəz' lɛɡz, wɑz dip ɪnʌf tə læp əɡɛns ðə soʊlz ə ðə ɹaɪɾɝz' buts.

Slowly, quietly, the Warder took them back across the stableyard, down the bank through the willows and into the Winespring Water. So close to the Winespring itself the cold, swift water, gleaming as it swirled around the horses' legs, was deep enough to lap against the soles of the riders' boots.

klaɪmɪŋ aʊɾ ɑn ðə fɑɹ bæŋk, ðə laɪn ə hɔɹsəz waʊn ɪts weɪ ʌndɝ ðə wɔɹɾɝz dɛf dɝɛkʃən, kipɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ɛni ʌv ðə vɪlədʒ haʊsəz. fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm læn stɑpt, saɪnɪŋ əm ɔl tə bi kwaɪət, ðoʊ noʊ wʌn ɛls hɝɾ əɹ sɔ ɛniθɪŋ. itʃ taɪm i dɪd, haʊɛvɝ, ənʌðɝ pətʃɹoʊl ə vɪlɪdʒɝz ən fɑɹmɝz sun pæst. sloʊli ðeɪ muv təwɔɹd ðə nɔɹθ ɛdʒ ə ðə vɪlədʒ.

Climbing out on the far bank, the line of horses wound its way under the Warder's deft direction, keeping away from any of the village houses. From time to time Lan stopped, signing them all to be quiet, though no one else heard or saw anything. Each time he did, however, another patrol of villagers and farmers soon passed. Slowly they moved toward the north edge of the village.

ɹænd pɪɹɾ ət ðə haɪ-pik haʊsəz ɪn ðə dɑɹk, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪmpɹɛs əm ɑn ɪz mɛmɹi. ə faɪn ædvɛntʃɝɝ aɪ æm, hi θɔt. hi wɑz nɑɾ ivən aʊɾ ə ðə vɪlədʒ jɛt, ən ɔlɹɛɾi hi wɑz hoʊmsɪk. bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt stɑp lʊkɪŋ.

Rand peered at the high-peaked houses in the dark, trying to impress them on his memory. A fine adventurer I am, he thought. He was not even out of the village yet, and already he was homesick. But he did not stop looking.

ðeɪ pæs bɪɑn ðə læs fɑɹmhaʊsəz ɑn ði aʊtskɝts ə ðə vɪlədʒ ən ɪndə ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd, pɛɹəlɛlɪŋ ðə nɔɹθ ɹoʊd ðət lɛd tə tɛɹən fɛɹi. ɹænd θɔt ðət ʃʊɹli noʊ naɪt skaɪ ɛlswɛɹ kəd bi əz bjuɾəfəl əz ðə tu ɹɪvɝz skaɪ. ðə klɪɹ blæk sim tə ɹitʃ tə fɝɛvɝ, ən mɪɹiəd stɑɹz ɡlim laɪk pɔɪns ə laɪt skæɾɝd θɹu kɹɪstəl. ðə mun, oʊnli ə θɪn slaɪs lɛs ðən fʊl, əpɪɹɾ ɔlmoʊs kloʊs ɪnʌf tə tʌtʃ, ɪf i stʃɹɛtʃt, ænd. . . .

They passed beyond the last farmhouses on the outskirts of the village and into the countryside, paralleling the North Road that led to Taren Ferry. Rand thought that surely no night sky elsewhere could be as beautiful as the Two Rivers sky. The clear black seemed to reach to forever, and myriad stars gleamed like points of light scattered through crystal. The moon, only a thin slice less than full, appeared almost close enough to touch, if he stretched, and. . . .

ə blæk ʃeɪp flu sloʊli əkɹɔs ðə sɪlvɝi bɔl ə ðə mun. ɹændz ɪnvɑləntɛɹi dʒɝk ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz hɔltəd ðə ɡɹeɪ. ə bæt, hi θɔt wikli, bʌɾ i nu ɪt wɑz nɑt. bæts wɝ ə kɑmən saɪɾ ʌv ən ivnɪŋ, dɑɹɾɪŋ æftɝ flaɪz ən baɪtmz ɪn ðə twaɪlaɪt. ðə wɪŋz ðət kæɹid ðɪs kɹitʃɝ maɪɾ əv ðə seɪm ʃeɪp, bʌt ðeɪ muvd wɪð ðə sloʊ, paʊɝfəl swip ʌv ə bɝɾ ə pɹeɪ. ən ɪt wɑz hʌntɪŋ. ðə weɪ ɪt kæs bæk ən fɔɹθ ɪn lɔŋ ɑɹks lɛf noʊ daʊɾ ə ðæt. wɝst ʌv ɔl wɑz ðə saɪz. fəɹ ə bæt tə sim soʊ lɑɹdʒ əɡɛns ðə mun ɪt wʊɾə hæd tə bi ɔlmoʊst wɪðɪn ɑɹmz ɹitʃ. hi tʃɹaɪd tə dʒʌdʒ ɪn ɪz maɪn haʊ fɑɹ əweɪ ɪt mʌs bi, ən haʊ bɪɡ. ðə bɑɾi ʌv ɪt hæd tə bi əz lɑɹdʒ əz ə mæn, ən ðə wɪŋz. . . . ɪt kɹɔs ðə feɪs ə ðə mun əɡɛn, wilɪŋ sʌɾənli daʊnwɝd tə bi ɪnɡʌlf baɪ ðə naɪt.

A black shape flew slowly across the silvery ball of the moon. Rand's involuntary jerk on the reins halted the gray. A bat, he thought weakly, but he knew it was not. Bats were a common sight of an evening, darting after flies and bitemes in the twilight. The wings that carried this creature might have the same shape, but they moved with the slow, powerful sweep of a bird of prey. And it was hunting. The way it cast back and forth in long arcs left no doubt of that. Worst of all was the size. For a bat to seem so large against the moon it would have had to be almost within arm's reach. He tried to judge in his mind how far away it must be, and how big. The body of it had to be as large as a man, and the wings. . . . It crossed the face of the moon again, wheeling suddenly downward to be engulfed by the night.

hi dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz ðət læn hæd ɹɪɾən bæk tə hɪm əntɪl ðə wɔɹɾɝ kɑɾ ɪz ɑɹm. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə sɪɾɪŋ hɪɹ ən stɛɹɪŋ æt, bɔɪ? wɪv tə kip muvɪŋ." ði ʌðɝz weɪɾəd bɪhaɪn læn.

He did not realize that Lan had ridden back to him until the Warder caught his arm. "What are you sitting here and staring at, boy? We have to keep moving." The others waited behind Lan.

hæf ɪkspɛktɪŋ tə bi toʊld i wɑz lɛɾɪŋ fɪɹ ə ðə tʃɹɑləks oʊvɝkʌm ɪz sɛns, ɹænd toʊld wʌɾ i hæd sin. hi hoʊp ðət læn wəd dɪsmɪs ɪɾ əz ə bæt, əɹ ə tʃɹɪk ə hɪz aɪz.

Half expecting to be told he was letting fear of the Trollocs overcome his sense, Rand told what he had seen. He hoped that Lan would dismiss it as a bat, or a trick of his eyes.

læn ɡɹaʊld ə wɝd, saʊndɪŋ əz ɪf ɪt lɛft ə bæd teɪst ɪn ɪz maʊθ. "dʒɹæɡkɝ." ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝ tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk stɛɹɾ ət ðə skaɪ nɝvəsli ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz, bʌt ðə ɡlimən ɡɹoʊn sɔfli.

Lan growled a word, sounding as if it left a bad taste in his mouth. "Draghkar." Egwene and the other Two Rivers folk stared at the sky nervously in all directions, but the gleeman groaned softly.

"jɛs," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz tu mʌtʃ tə hoʊp ʌðɝwaɪz. ən ɪf ðə mɹdʒɹɑl əz ə dʒɹæɡkɝ əɾ ɪz kəmænd, ðən hɪl sun noʊ wɛɹ wi ɑɹ, ɪf i dʌz nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. wi mʌs muv mɔɹ kwɪkli ðən wi kən kɹɔs-kʌntʃɹi. wi meɪ stɪl ɹitʃ tɛɹən fɛɹi əhɛɾ ə ðə mɹdʒɹɑl, ən i ən ɪz tʃɹɑləks wɪl nɑt kɹɔs əz izəli əz wi."

"Yes," Moiraine said. "It is too much to hope otherwise. And if the Myrddraal has a Draghkar at his command, then he will soon know where we are, if he does not already. We must move more quickly than we can cross-country. We may still reach Taren Ferry ahead of the Myrddraal, and he and his Trollocs will not cross as easily as we."

"eɪ dʒɹæɡkɝ?" ɛɡwin sɛd. "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?"

"A Draghkar?" Egwene said. "What is it?"

ɪt wɑz tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn u ænsɝɾ əɹ hɔɹsli. "ɪn ðə wɔɹ ðəɾ ɛndəd ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, wɝs ðən tʃɹɑləks ən hæfmən wɝ kɹieɪɾəd."

It was Thom Merrilin who answered her hoarsely. "In the war that ended the Age of Legends, worse than Trollocs and Halfmen were created."

mɔɪɹeɪnz hɛd dʒɝk təwɔɹɾ ɪm əz i spoʊk. nɑɾ ivən ðə dɑɹk kəd haɪd ðə ʃɑɹpnəs ə hɝ lʊk.

Moiraine's head jerked toward him as he spoke. Not even the dark could hide the sharpness of her look.

bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn kəɾ æsk ðə ɡlimən fəɹ mɔɹ, læn bɪɡæn ɡɪvɪŋ dɝɛkʃənz. "wi teɪk tə ðə nɔɹθ ɹoʊd, naʊ. fəɹ jəɹ laɪvz, fɑloʊ maɪ lɛd, kip ʌp ən kip təɡɛðɝ."

Before anyone could ask the gleeman for more, Lan began giving directions. "We take to the North Road, now. For your lives, follow my lead, keep up and keep together."

hi wild ɪz hɔɹs əbaʊt, ən ði ʌðɝz ɡæləpt wɝdləsli æftɝ hɪm.

He wheeled his horse about, and the others galloped wordlessly after him.


tʃæptɝ ɪlɛvən


CHAPTER 11

ðə ɹoʊd tə tɛɹən fɛɹi


The Road to Taren Ferry

ɑn ðə hɑɹd-pæk dɝɾ ə ðə nɔɹθ ɹoʊd ðə hɔɹsəz stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt, meɪnz ən teɪlz stʃɹimɪŋ bæk ɪn ðə munlaɪɾ əz ðeɪ ɹeɪs nɔɹθwɝd, hʊvz paʊndɪŋ ə stɛɾi ɹɪðəm. læn lɛd ðə weɪ, blæk hɔɹs ən ʃædoʊ-klæd ɹaɪɾɝ ɔl bʌɾ ɪnvɪzəbəl ɪn ðə koʊl naɪt. mɔɪɹeɪnz waɪt mɛɹ, mætʃɪŋ ðə stæljən stʃɹaɪd fəɹ stʃɹaɪd, wɑz ə peɪl dɑɹt spiɾɪŋ θɹu ðə dɑɹk. ðə ɹɛs fɑloʊɾ ɪn ə taɪt laɪn, əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɔl taɪd tə ə ɹoʊp wɪð wʌn ɛn ɪn ðə wɔɹɾɝz hænz.

On the hard-packed dirt of the North Road the horses stretched out, manes and tails streaming back in the moonlight as they raced northward, hooves pounding a steady rhythm. Lan led the way, black horse and shadow-clad rider all but invisible in the cold night. Moiraine's white mare, matching the stallion stride for stride, was a pale dart speeding through the dark. The rest followed in a tight line, as if they were all tied to a rope with one end in the Warder's hands.

ɹænd ɡæləp læst ɪn laɪn, wɪð tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn dʒʌst əhɛɾ ən ði ʌðɝz lɛs dɪstɪŋk bɪɑnd. ðə ɡlimən nɛvɝ tɝn ɪz hɛd, ɹɪzɝvɪŋ ɪz aɪz fəɹ wɛɹ ðeɪ ɹæn, nɑt wʌt ðeɪ ɹæn fɹʌm. ɪf tʃɹɑləks əpɪɹd bɪhaɪnd, əɹ ðə feɪɾ ɑn ɪts saɪlən hɔɹs, əɹ ðət flaɪɪŋ kɹitʃɝ, ðə dʒɹæɡkɝ, ɪt wəd bi ʌp tə ɹænd tə saʊn ən əlɑɹm.

Rand galloped last in line, with Thom Merrilin just ahead and the others less distinct beyond. The gleeman never turned his head, reserving his eyes for where they ran, not what they ran from. If Trollocs appeared behind, or the Fade on its silent horse, or that flying creature, the Draghkar, it would be up to Rand to sound an alarm.

ɛvɹi fju mɪnəts i kɹeɪn ɪz nɛk tə pɪɹ bɪhaɪnd waɪl i klʌŋ tə klaʊdz meɪn ən ɹeɪnz. ðə dʒɹæɡkɝ. . . . wɝs ðən tʃɹɑləks ən feɪdz, tɑm hæd sɛd. bʌt ðə skaɪ wɑz ɛmpti, ən oʊnli dɑɹknəs ən ʃædoʊz mɛɾ ɪz aɪz ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ʃædoʊz ðət kəd haɪɾ ən ɑɹmi.

Every few minutes he craned his neck to peer behind while he clung to Cloud's mane and reins. The Draghkar. . . . Worse than Trollocs and Fades, Thom had said. But the sky was empty, and only darkness and shadows met his eyes on the ground. Shadows that could hide an army.

naʊ ðət ðə ɡɹeɪ hæd bɪn lɛt lus tə ɹʌn, ði ænəməl spɛd θɹu ðə naɪt laɪk ə ɡoʊst, izəli kipɪŋ peɪs wɪð lænz stæljən. ən klaʊd wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ fæstɝ. hi wɑntəd tə kætʃ ðə blæk, stʃɹeɪn tə kætʃ ðə blæk. ɹænd hæd tə kip ə fɝm hæn ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz tə hoʊld ɪm bæk. klaʊd lʌnʒd əɡɛnst ɪz ɹɪstʃɹeɪn əz ɪf ðə ɡɹeɪ θɔt ðɪs wɝ ə ɹeɪs, faɪɾɪŋ ɪm fəɹ mæstɝi wɪð ɛvɹi stʃɹaɪd. ɹænd klʌŋ tə sæɾəl ən ɹeɪnz wɪð ɛvɹi mʌsəl tɔt. fɝvənli hi hoʊpt ɪz maʊn dɪd nɑt dɪtɛk haʊ ənizi hi wɑz. ɪf klaʊd dɪd, hi wəd luz ðə wʌn ɹil ɛdʒ i hɛld, haʊɛvɝ pɹɪkɛɹiəsli.

Now that the gray had been let loose to run, the animal sped through the night like a ghost, easily keeping pace with Lan's stallion. And Cloud wanted to go faster. He wanted to catch the black, strained to catch the black. Rand had to keep a firm hand on the reins to hold him back. Cloud lunged against his restraint as if the gray thought this were a race, fighting him for mastery with every stride. Rand clung to saddle and reins with every muscle taut. Fervently he hoped his mount did not detect how uneasy he was. If Cloud did, he would lose the one real edge he held, however precariously.

laɪɪŋ loʊ ɑn klaʊdz nɛk, ɹænd kɛpt ə wɝiɾ aɪ ɑn bɛlə ən ɑn əɹ ɹaɪɾɝ. wən i hæd sɛd ðə ʃæɡi mɛɹ kəd steɪ wɪð ði ʌðɝz, hi hæd nɑt mɛn ɑn ðə ɹʌn. ʃi kɛpt ʌp naʊ oʊnli baɪ ɹʌnɪŋ əz i hæd nɑt θɔt ʃi kʊd. læn hæd nɑt wɑntəɾ ɛɡwin ɪn ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ. wəɾ i sloʊ fəɹ əɹ ɪf bɛlə bɪɡæn tə flæɡ? əɹ wəɾ i tʃɹaɪ tə liv əɹ bɪhaɪnd? ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ θɔt ɹænd ən ɪz fɹɛnz wɝ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪn səm weɪ, bʌt fəɹ ɔl ə mɔɪɹeɪnz tɔk ə ðə pæɾɝn, hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðeɪ ɪnkluɾəd ɛɡwin ɪn ðəɾ ɪmpɔɹɾəns.

Lying low on Cloud's neck, Rand kept a worried eye on Bela and on her rider. When he had said the shaggy mare could stay with the others, he had not meant on the run. She kept up now only by running as he had not thought she could. Lan had not wanted Egwene in their number. Would he slow for her if Bela began to flag? Or would he try to leave her behind? The Aes Sedai and the Warder thought Rand and his friends were important in some way, but for all of Moiraine's talk of the Pattern, he did not think they included Egwene in that importance.

ɪf bɛlə fɛl bæk, hi wəd fɔl bæk, tu, wʌtɛvɝ mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn hæd tə seɪ əbaʊɾ ɪt. bæk wɛɹ ðə feɪɾ ən ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ. bæk wɛɹ ðə dʒɹæɡkɝ wɑz. wɪð ɔl ɪz hɑɹɾ ən dɛspɝeɪʃən i saɪlənli ʃaʊɾəd ət bɛlə tə ɹʌn laɪk ðə wɪnd, saɪlənli tʃɹaɪd tə wɪl stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪndə hɝ. ɹʌn! hɪz skɪn pɹɪkəld, ən ɪz boʊnz fɛlt əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ fɹizɪŋ, ɹɛɾi tə splɪɾ oʊpən. ðə laɪt hɛlp hɝ, ɹʌn! ən bɛlə ɹæn.

If Bela fell back, he would fall back, too, whatever Moiraine and Lan had to say about it. Back where the Fade and the Trollocs were. Back where the Draghkar was. With all his heart and desperation he silently shouted at Bela to run like the wind, silently tried to will strength into her. Run! His skin prickled, and his bones felt as if they were freezing, ready to split open. The Light help her, run! And Bela ran.

ɑn ən ɑn ðeɪ spɛd, nɔɹθwɝɾ ɪndə ðə naɪt, taɪm feɪɾɪŋ ɪndə ən ɪndɪstɪŋk blɝ. naʊ ən əɡɛn ðə laɪts ə fɑɹmhaʊsəz flæʃt ɪndə saɪt, ðən dɪsəpɪɹɾ əz kwɪkli əz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. dɑɡz' ʃɑɹp tʃælənʒɪz feɪɾəd swɪfli bɪhaɪnd, əɹ kʌɾ ɔf əbɹʌpli əz ðə dɑɡz dɪsaɪɾɪd ðeɪ hæd bɪn tʃeɪst əweɪ. ðeɪ ɹeɪs θɹu dɑɹknəs ɹɪlivd oʊnli baɪ wɔɾɝi peɪl munlaɪt, ə dɑɹknəs wɛɹ tʃɹiz əlɔŋ ðə ɹoʊd lumd ʌp wɪθaʊt wɔɹnɪŋ, ðən wɝ ɡɔn. fəɹ ðə ɹɛst, mɝk sɝaʊndəd ðɛm, ən oʊnli ə sɑlətɛɹi naɪt-bɝdz kɹaɪ, loʊnli ən mɔɹnfəl, dɪstɝb ðə stɛɾi paʊndɪŋ ə hʊvz.

On and on they sped, northward into the night, time fading into an indistinct blur. Now and again the lights of farmhouses flashed into sight, then disappeared as quickly as imagination. Dogs' sharp challenges faded swiftly behind, or cut off abruptly as the dogs decided they had been chased away. They raced through darkness relieved only by watery pale moonlight, a darkness where trees along the road loomed up without warning, then were gone. For the rest, murk surrounded them, and only a solitary night-bird's cry, lonely and mournful, disturbed the steady pounding of hooves.

əbɹʌpli læn sloʊd, ðən bɹɔt ðə faɪl ə hɔɹsəz tə ə stɑp. ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ lɔŋ ðeɪ hæd bɪn muvɪŋ, bʌɾ ə sɑft eɪk fɪld ɪz lɛɡz fɹəm ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə sæɾəl. əhɛɾ ə ðɛm ɪn ðə naɪt, laɪts spɑɹkəld, əz ɪf ə tɔl swɔɹm ə faɪɝəfliz hɛld wʌn pleɪs əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz.

Abruptly Lan slowed, then brought the file of horses to a stop. Rand was not sure how long they had been moving, but a soft ache filled his legs from gripping the saddle. Ahead of them in the night, lights sparkled, as if a tall swarm of fireflies held one place among the trees.

ɹænd fɹaʊn ət ðə laɪts ɪn pʌzəlmənt, ðən sʌɾənli ɡæspt wɪð sɝpɹaɪz. ðə faɪɝəfliz wɝ wɪndoʊz, ðə wɪndoʊz ə haʊsəz kʌvɝɪŋ ðə saɪdz ən tɑp ʌv ə hɪl. ɪt wɑz wɑtʃ hɪl. hi kəd hɑɹdli bɪliv ðeɪ hæd kʌm soʊ fɑɹ. ðeɪ hæd pɹɑbli meɪd ðə dʒɝni əz fæst əz ɪt hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn tʃɹævəld. fɑloʊɪŋ lænz ɪɡzæmpəl, ɹænd ən tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn dɪsmaʊntɪd. klaʊd stʊd hɛd daʊn, saɪdz hivɪŋ. læðɝ, ɔlmoʊst ɪndɪstɪŋɡwɪʃəbəl fɹəm ðə hɔɹsəz smoʊki saɪdz, flɛk ðə ɡɹeɪz nɛk ən ʃoʊldɝz. ɹænd θɔt ðət klaʊd wəd nɑt bi kæɹiɪŋ ɛniwʌn fɝðɝ ðət naɪt.

Rand frowned at the lights in puzzlement, then suddenly gasped with surprise. The fireflies were windows, the windows of houses covering the sides and top of a hill. It was Watch Hill. He could hardly believe they had come so far. They had probably made the journey as fast as it had ever been traveled. Following Lan's example, Rand and Thom Merrilin dismounted. Cloud stood head down, sides heaving. Lather, almost indistinguishable from the horse's smoky sides, flecked the gray's neck and shoulders. Rand thought that Cloud would not be carrying anyone further that night.

"mʌtʃ əz aɪ wəd laɪk tə pʊɾ ɔl ðiz vɪlədʒəz bɪhaɪn mi," tɑm ənaʊnst, "ə fju aʊɝz ɹɛst wəd nɑt ɡoʊ əmɪs ɹaɪt naʊ. ʃʊɹli wɪv ɪnʌf ʌv ə lɛd tə əlaʊ ðæt?"

"Much as I would like to put all these villages behind me," Thom announced, "a few hours rest would not go amiss right now. Surely we have enough of a lead to allow that?"

ɹænd stʃɹɛtʃt, nʌklɪŋ ðə smɔl ə hɪz bæk. "ɪf wɝ stɑpɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə naɪɾ ɪn wɑtʃ hɪl, wi meɪ əz wɛl ɡoʊ ɑn ʌp."

Rand stretched, knuckling the small of his back. "If we're stopping the rest of the night in Watch Hill, we may as well go on up."

ə veɪɡɹənt ɡʌst ʌv wɪn bɹɔɾ ə fɹæɡmən ə sɔŋ fɹəm ðə vɪlədʒ, ən smɛlz ə kʊkɪŋ ðət meɪɾ ɪz maʊθ wɔɾɝ. ðeɪ wɝ stɪl sɛləbɹeɪɾɪŋ ɪn wɑtʃ hɪl. ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ tʃɹɑləks tə dɪstɝb ðɛɹ bɛl taɪn. hi lʊk fəɹ ɛɡwin. ʃi wɑz linɪŋ əɡɛns bɛlə, slʌmpt wɪð wɪɹinəs. ði ʌðɝz wɝ klaɪmɪŋ daʊn əz wɛl, wɪð mɛni ə saɪ ən mʌtʃ stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ʌv eɪkɪŋ mʌsəlz. oʊnli ðə wɔɹɾɝ ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃoʊd noʊ vɪzəbəl saɪn ə fətiɡ.

A vagrant gust of wind brought a fragment of song from the village, and smells of cooking that made his mouth water. They were still celebrating in Watch Hill. There had been no Trollocs to disturb their Bel Tine. He looked for Egwene. She was leaning against Bela, slumped with weariness. The others were climbing down as well, with many a sigh and much stretching of aching muscles. Only the Warder and the Aes Sedai showed no visible sign of fatigue.

"aɪ kəd də wɪð səm sɪŋɪŋ," mæt pʊɾ ɪn taɪɹədli. "æn meɪbi ə hɑt mʌɾən paɪ ət ðə waɪt bɔɹ." pɔzɪŋ, hi æɾəd, "aɪv nɛvɝ bɪn fɝðɝ ðən wɑtʃ hɪl. ðə waɪt bɔɹz nɑt nɪɹli əz ɡʊɾ əz ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn."

"I could do with some singing," Mat put in tiredly. "And maybe a hot mutton pie at the White Boar." Pausing, he added, "I've never been further than Watch Hill. The White Boar's not nearly as good as the Winespring Inn."

"ðə waɪt bɔɹ ɪzən soʊ bæd," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ə mʌɾən paɪ fəɹ mi, tu. ən lɑts ə hɑt ti tə teɪk ðə tʃɪl ɔf maɪ boʊnz."

"The White Boar isn't so bad," Perrin said. "A mutton pie for me, too. And lots of hot tea to take the chill off my bones."

"wi kænɑt stɑp əntɪl wəɹ əkɹɔs ðə tɛɹən," læn sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "nɑt fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ə fju mɪnəts."

"We cannot stop until we are across the Taren," Lan said sharply. "Not for more than a few minutes."

"bʌt ðə hɔɹsəz," ɹænd pɹətɛstəd. "wil ɹʌn əm tə dɛθ ɪf wi tʃɹaɪ tə ɡoʊ ɛni fɝðɝ tənaɪt. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ, ʃʊɹli jə - "

"But the horses," Rand protested. "We'll run them to death if we try to go any further tonight. Moiraine Sedai, surely you - "

hi hæd veɪɡli noʊɾəst əɹ muvɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə hɔɹsəz, bʌɾ i hæd nɑt peɪɾ ɛni ɹil ətɛnʃən tə wʌt ʃi dɪd. naʊ ʃi bɹʌʃt pæst ɪm tə leɪ hɝ hænz ɑn klaʊdz nɛk. ɹænd fɛl saɪlənt. sʌɾənli ðə hɔɹs tɔst ɪz hɛd wɪð ə sɑft wɪkɝ, nɪɹli pʊlɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnz fɹəm ɹændz hænz. ðə ɡɹeɪ dænst ə stɛp saɪdweɪz, əz ɹɛstɪv əz ɪf i hæd spɛn ə wik ɪn ə steɪbəl. wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd mɔɪɹeɪn wɛn tə bɛlə.

He had vaguely noticed her moving among the horses, but he had not paid any real attention to what she did. Now she brushed past him to lay her hands on Cloud's neck. Rand fell silent. Suddenly the horse tossed his head with a soft whicker, nearly pulling the reins from Rand's hands. The gray danced a step sideways, as restive as if he had spent a week in a stable. Without a word Moiraine went to Bela.

"aɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ ʃi kəd də ðæt," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli tə læn, hɪz tʃiks hɑt.

"I did not know she could do that," Rand said softly to Lan, his cheeks hot.

"ju, ʌv ɔl pipəl, ʃʊɾə səspɛktəɾ ɪt," ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɹɪplaɪd. "ju wɑtʃt əɹ wɪð jəɹ fɑðɝ. ʃɪl wɑʃ ɔl ðə fətiɡ əweɪ. fɝs fɹəm ðə hɔɹsəz, ðən fɹəm ðə ɹɛst ə ju."

"You, of all people, should have suspected it," the Warder replied. "You watched her with your father. She will wash all the fatigue away. First from the horses, then from the rest of you."

"ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs. nɑt ju?"

"The rest of us. Not you?"

"nɑt mi, ʃifɝɾɝ. aɪ doʊnt niɾ ɪt, nɑt jɛt. ən nɑt hɝ. wʌt ʃi kən də fəɹ ʌðɝz, ʃi kænɑt də fəɹ hɝsɛlf. oʊnli wʌn ʌv əs wɪl ɹaɪd taɪɝd. jə hæd bɛɾɝ hoʊp ʃi dʌz nɑt ɡɹoʊ tu taɪɝd bɪfɔɹ wi ɹitʃ tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"Not me, sheepherder. I don't need it, not yet. And not her. What she can do for others, she cannot do for herself. Only one of us will ride tired. You had better hope she does not grow too tired before we reach Tar Valon."

"tu taɪɝd fəɹ wʌt?" ɹænd æsk ðə wɔɹɾɝ.

"Too tired for what?" Rand asked the Warder.

"ju wɝ ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt jəɹ bɛlə, ɹænd," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd fɹəm wɛɹ ʃi stʊd baɪ ðə mɛɹ. "ʃi hæz ə ɡʊd hɑɹt, ən əz mʌtʃ stʌbɝnnəs əz ðə ɹɛst ə jə tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk. stʃɹeɪnʒ əz ɪt simz, ʃi meɪ bi ðə list wɪɹi ʌv ɔl."

"You were right about your Bela, Rand," Moiraine said from where she stood by the mare. "She has a good heart, and as much stubbornness as the rest of you Two Rivers folk. Strange as it seems, she may be the least weary of all."

ə skɹim ɹɪp ðə dɑɹknəs, ə saʊn laɪk ə mæn daɪɪŋ ʌndɝ ʃɑɹp naɪvz, ən wɪŋz swup loʊ əbʌv ðə pɑɹɾi. ðə naɪt dipən ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ ðət swɛpt oʊvɝ ðɛm. wɪð pænɪkt kɹaɪz ðə hɔɹsəz ɹɪɹd waɪldli.

A scream ripped the darkness, a sound like a man dying under sharp knives, and wings swooped low above the party. The night deepened in the shadow that swept over them. With panicked cries the horses reared wildly.

ðə wɪn ə ðə dʒɹæɡkɝz wɪŋz biɾ ət ɹænd wɪð ə fil laɪk ðə tʌtʃ ə slaɪm, laɪk tʃɪɾɝɪŋ ɪn ðə dæŋk dɪmnəs ʌv ə naɪtmɛɹ. hi hæd noʊ taɪm ivən tə fil ðə fɪɹ ʌv ɪt, fəɹ klaʊɾ ɪksploʊɾəd ɪndə ði ɛɹ wɪð ə skɹim ə hɪz oʊn, twɪstɪŋ dɛspɝətli əz ɪf ətɛmptɪŋ tə ʃeɪk ɔf səm klɪŋɪŋ θɪŋ. ɹænd, hæŋɪŋ ɑntu ðə ɹeɪnz, wɑz dʒɝkt ɔf ɪz fiɾ ən dʒɹæɡd əkɹɔs ðə ɡɹaʊnd, klaʊd skɹimɪŋ əz ðoʊ ðə bɪɡ ɡɹeɪ fɛlt wʊlvz tɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪz hɑks.

The wind of the Draghkar's wings beat at Rand with a feel like the touch of slime, like chittering in the dank dimness of a nightmare. He had no time even to feel the fear of it, for Cloud exploded into the air with a scream of his own, twisting desperately as if attempting to shake off some clinging thing. Rand, hanging onto the reins, was jerked off his feet and dragged across the ground, Cloud screaming as though the big gray felt wolves tearing at his hocks.

sʌmhaʊ hi meɪnteɪn ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz; juzɪŋ ði ʌðɝ hæn əz mʌtʃ əz ɪz lɛɡz i skɹæmbəld ɑntu hɪz fit, teɪkɪŋ lipɪŋ, stæɡɝɪŋ stɛps tə kip fɹəm biɪŋ pʊl daʊn əɡɛn. hɪz bɹɛθ keɪm ɪn ɹæɡəd pæns ə dɛspɝeɪʃən. hi kəd nɑt lɛt klaʊd ɡɛɾ əweɪ. hi θɹu aʊɾ ə fɹæntɪk hænd, bɛɹli kætʃɪŋ ðə bɹaɪɾəl. klaʊd ɹɪɹd, lɪftɪŋ ɪm ɪndə ði ɛɹ; ɹænd klʌŋ hɛlpləsli, hoʊpɪŋ əɡɛns hoʊp ðət ðə hɔɹs wəd kwaɪəɾən.

Somehow he maintained his grip on the reins; using the other hand as much as his legs he scrambled onto his feet, taking leaping, staggering steps to keep from being pulled down again. His breath came in ragged pants of desperation. He could not let Cloud get away. He threw out a frantic hand, barely catching the bridle. Cloud reared, lifting him into the air; Rand clung helplessly, hoping against hope that the horse would quieten.

ðə ʃɑk ə lændɪŋ dʒɑɹd ɹænd tə hɪz tiθ, bʌt sʌɾənli ðə ɡɹeɪ wɑz stɪl, nɑstʃɹəlz flɛɹɪŋ ən aɪz ɹoʊlɪŋ, stɪf-lɛɡəɾ ən tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. ɹænd wɑz tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ əz wɛl, ən ɔl bʌt hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ðə bɹaɪɾəl. ðət dʒoʊl mʌst əv ʃeɪkən ðə ful ænəməl, tu, hi θɔt. hi tʊk θɹi əɹ fɔɹ dip, ʃeɪki bɹɛθs. oʊnli ðən kəɾ i lʊk ɝaʊn ən si wʌt hæd hæpən tə ði ʌðɝz.

The shock of landing jarred Rand to his teeth, but suddenly the gray was still, nostrils flaring and eyes rolling, stiff-legged and trembling. Rand was trembling as well, and all but hanging from the bridle. That jolt must have shaken the fool animal, too, he thought. He took three or four deep, shaky breaths. Only then could he look around and see what had happened to the others.

keɪɑs ɹeɪn əmʌŋ ðə pɑɹɾi. ðeɪ klʌtʃt ɹeɪnz əɡɛns dʒɝkɪŋ hɛdz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ wɪð lɪɾəl səksɛs tə kɑm ðə ɹɪɹɪŋ hɔɹsəz ðət dʒɹæɡd əm əbaʊɾ ɪn ə mɪlɪŋ mæs. oʊnli tu simɪŋli hæd noʊ tʃɹʌbəl əɾ ɔl wɪð ðɛɹ maʊns. mɔɪɹeɪn sæt stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl, ðə waɪt mɛɹ stɛpɪŋ dɛləkətli əweɪ fɹəm ðə kənfjuʒən əz ɪf nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi hæd hæpənd. ɑn fʊt, læn skæn ðə skaɪ, sɔɹɾ ɪn wʌn hæn ən ɹeɪnz ɪn ði ʌðɝ; ðə slik blæk stæljən stʊd kwaɪətli bɪsaɪd hɪm.

Chaos reigned among the party. They clutched reins against jerking heads, trying with little success to calm the rearing horses that dragged them about in a milling mass. Only two seemingly had no trouble at all with their mounts. Moiraine sat straight in her saddle, the white mare stepping delicately away from the confusion as if nothing at all out of the ordinary had happened. On foot, Lan scanned the sky, sword in one hand and reins in the other; the sleek black stallion stood quietly beside him.

saʊnz ə mɛɹɪmækɪŋ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ keɪm fɹəm wɑtʃ hɪl. ðoʊz ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ mʌst əv hɝd ðə kɹaɪ, tu. ɹænd nu ðeɪ wəd lɪsən əwaɪl, ən pɝhæps wɑtʃ fəɹ wʌt hæd kɑzd ɪt, ðən ɹɪtɝn tə ðɛɹ dʒɑləɾi. ðeɪ wəd sun fɝɡɛt ði ɪnsəɾənt, ɪts mɛmɹi səbmɝdʒ baɪ sɔŋ ən fuɾ ən dæns ən fʌn. pɝhæps wən ðeɪ hɝd ðə nuz ʌv wʌt hæd hæpən ɪn ɛmənz fil səm wəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ən wʌndɝ. ə fɪɾəl bɪɡæn tə pleɪ, ən æftɝ ə moʊmən ə flut dʒɔɪn ɪn. ðə vɪlədʒ wɑz ɹɪzumɪŋ ɪts sɛləbɹeɪʃən.

Sounds of merrymaking no longer came from Watch Hill. Those in the village must have heard the cry, too. Rand knew they would listen awhile, and perhaps watch for what had caused it, then return to their jollity. They would soon forget the incident, its memory submerged by song and food and dance and fun. Perhaps when they heard the news of what had happened in Emond's Field some would remember, and wonder. A fiddle began to play, and after a moment a flute joined in. The village was resuming its celebration.

"maʊnt!" læn kəmændəd kɝtli. ʃiðɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd, hi lɛpt ɑntu ðə stæljən. "ðə dʒɹæɡkɝ wəd nɑɾ əv ʃoʊɾ ɪtsɛlf ənlɛs ɪt hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɹipɔɹɾəd əɹ wɛɹəbaʊts tə ðə mɹdʒɹɑl." ənʌðɝ stʃɹaɪɾənt ʃɹik dʒɹɪftəd daʊn fɹəm fɑɹ əbʌv, feɪntɝ bʌt noʊ lɛs hɑɹʃ. ðə mjuzɪk fɹəm wɑtʃ hɪl saɪlənst ɹæədli wʌns mɔɹ. "ɪt tʃɹæks əs naʊ, mɑɹkɪŋ əs fəɹ ðə hæfmən. hi woʊn bi fɑɹ."

"Mount!" Lan commanded curtly. Sheathing his sword, he leaped onto the stallion. "The Draghkar would not have showed itself unless it had already reported our whereabouts to the Myrddraal." Another strident shriek drifted down from far above, fainter but no less harsh. The music from Watch Hill silenced raggedly once more. "It tracks us now, marking us for the Halfman. He won't be far."

ðə hɔɹsəz, fɹɛʃ naʊ əz wɛl əz fɪɹ-stʃɹʌk, pɹænst ən bækt əweɪ fɹəm ðoʊz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə maʊnt. ə kɝsɪŋ tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn wɑz ðə fɝst ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl, bʌt ði ʌðɝz wɝ ʌp sun æftɝ. ɔl bʌt wʌn.

The horses, fresh now as well as fear-struck, pranced and backed away from those trying to mount. A cursing Thom Merrilin was the first into his saddle, but the others were up soon after. All but one.

"hɝi, ɹænd!" ɛɡwin ʃaʊɾəd. ðə dʒɹæɡkɝ ɡeɪv ʃɹɪl vɔɪs wʌns mɔɹ, ən bɛlə ɹæn ə fju stɛps bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd ɹeɪn ðə mɛɹ ɪn. "hɝi!"

"Hurry, Rand!" Egwene shouted. The Draghkar gave shrill voice once more, and Bela ran a few steps before she could rein the mare in. "Hurry!"

wɪð ə stɑɹt ɹænd ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə maʊn klaʊɾ i hæd bɪn stændɪŋ ðəɹ stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə skaɪ ɪn ə veɪn ətɛmp tə loʊkeɪt ðə sɔɹs ə ðoʊz vaɪl ʃɹiks. mɔɹ, ɔl ʌnəwɛɹ, hi hæd dʒɹɔn tæmz sɔɹɾ əz ɪf tə faɪt ðə flaɪɪŋ θɪŋ.

With a start Rand realized that instead of trying to mount Cloud he had been standing there staring at the sky in a vain attempt to locate the source of those vile shrieks. More, all unaware, he had drawn Tam's sword as if to fight the flying thing.

hɪz feɪs ɹɛɾənd, meɪkɪŋ ɪm ɡlæd fəɹ ðə naɪt tə haɪd hɪm. ɔkwɝdli, wɪð wʌn hæn ɑkjəpaɪd baɪ ðə ɹeɪnz, hi ɹeɪ-ʃiðd ðə bleɪd, ɡlænsɪŋ heɪstəli ət ði ʌðɝz. mɔɪɹeɪn, læn, ən ɛɡwin ɔl wɝ lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ðoʊ hi kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ haʊ mʌtʃ ðeɪ kəd si ɪn ðə munlaɪt. ðə ɹɛst sim tu əbzɔɹbd wɪð kipɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl tə peɪ hɪm ɛni maɪnd. hi pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn ðə pɑməl ən ɹitʃt ðə sæɾəl ɪn wʌn lip, əz ɪf i hæd bɪn duɪŋ ðə laɪk ɔl ɪz laɪf. ɪf ɛni ʌv ɪz fɹɛnz hæd noʊɾəst ðə sɔɹd, hi wəd ʃʊɹli hɪɹ əbaʊɾ ɪt leɪɾɝ. ðəɹ wəd bi taɪm ɪnʌf tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪt ðɛn.

His face reddened, making him glad for the night to hide him. Awkwardly, with one hand occupied by the reins, he re-sheathed the blade, glancing hastily at the others. Moiraine, Lan, and Egwene all were looking at him, though he could not be sure how much they could see in the moonlight. The rest seemed too absorbed with keeping their horses under control to pay him any mind. He put a hand on the pommel and reached the saddle in one leap, as if he had been doing the like all his life. If any of his friends had noticed the sword, he would surely hear about it later. There would be time enough to worry about it then.

əz sun əz i wɑz ɪn ðə sæɾəl ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɔf əɾ ə ɡæləp əɡɛn, ʌp ðə ɹoʊɾ ən baɪ ðə doʊm-laɪk hɪl. dɑɡz bɑɹkt ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ; ðɛɹ pæsədʒ wɑz nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli ənnoʊɾɪst. əɹ meɪbi ðə dɑɡz smɛl tʃɹɑləks, ɹænd θɔt. ðə bɑɹkɪŋ ən ðə vɪlədʒ laɪts əlaɪk vænɪʃt kwɪkli bɪhaɪn ðɛm.

As soon as he was in the saddle they were all off at a gallop again, up the road and by the dome-like hill. Dogs barked in the village; their passage was not entirely unnoticed. Or maybe the dogs smelled Trollocs, Rand thought. The barking and the village lights alike vanished quickly behind them.

ðeɪ ɡæləpt ɪn ə nɑt, hɔɹsəz ɔl bʌt dʒɑsəlɪŋ təɡɛðɝ əz ðeɪ ɹæn. læn ɔɹɾɝd əm tə spɹɛɾ aʊɾ əɡɛn, bʌt noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə bi ivən ə lɪɾəl əloʊn ɪn ðə naɪt. ə skɹim keɪm fɹəm haɪ oʊvɝhɛd. ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɡeɪv ʌp ən lɛɾ əm ɹʌn klʌstɝd.

They galloped in a knot, horses all but jostling together as they ran. Lan ordered them to spread out again, but no one wanted to be even a little alone in the night. A scream came from high overhead. The Warder gave up and let them run clustered.

ɹænd wɑz kloʊs bɪhaɪn mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn, ðə ɡɹeɪ stʃɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn ən ɛfɝt tə fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf bɪtwin ðə wɔɹɾɝz blæk ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪz tʃɹɪm mɛɹ. ɛɡwin ən ðə ɡlimən ɹeɪst ɑn iðɝ flæŋk ə hɪm, waɪl ɹændz fɹɛnz kɹaʊɾəd ɪn bɪhaɪnd. klaʊd, spɝd baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡkɝz kɹaɪz, ɹæn bɪɑn ɛniθɪŋ ɹænd kəd də tə sloʊ hɪm ivən hæɾ i wɪʃt tə, jɛt ðə ɡɹeɪ kəd nɑt ɡeɪn soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə stɛp ɑn ði ʌðɝ tu hɔɹsəz.

Rand was close behind Moiraine and Lan, the gray straining in an effort to force himself between the Warder's black and the Aes Sedai's trim mare. Egwene and the gleeman raced on either flank of him, while Rand's friends crowded in behind. Cloud, spurred by the Draghkar's cries, ran beyond anything Rand could do to slow him even had he wished to, yet the gray could not gain so much as a step on the other two horses.

ðə dʒɹæɡkɝz ʃɹik tʃælənʒd ðə naɪt.

The Draghkar's shriek challenged the night.

staʊt bɛlə ɹæn wɪð nɛk aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt ən teɪl ən meɪn stʃɹimɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪn ə hɝ ɹʌnɪŋ, mætʃɪŋ ðə lɑɹdʒɝ hɔɹsəz' ɛvɹi stʃɹaɪd. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ mʌst əv dʌn sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən sɪmpli ɹɪɾɪŋ əɹ ə fətiɡ.

Stout Bela ran with neck outstretched and tail and mane streaming in the wind of her running, matching the larger horses' every stride. The Aes Sedai must have done something more than simply ridding her of fatigue.

ɛɡwinz feɪs ɪn ðə munlaɪt wɑz smaɪlɪŋ ɪn ɪksaɪɾəd dɪlaɪt. hɝ bɹeɪd stʃɹim bɪhaɪn laɪk ðə hɔɹsəz' meɪnz, ən ðə ɡlim ɪn əɹ aɪz wɑz nɑɾ ɔl fɹəm ðə mun, ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ. hɪz maʊθ dʒɹɑpt oʊpən ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, əntɪl ə swɑloʊd baɪtim sɛɾ ɪm ɔf ɪndə ə fɪɾ ə kɑfɪŋ.

Egwene's face in the moonlight was smiling in excited delight. Her braid streamed behind like the horses' manes, and the gleam in her eyes was not all from the moon, Rand was sure. His mouth dropped open in surprise, until a swallowed biteme set him off into a fit of coughing.

læn mʌst əv æskt ə kwɛstʃən, fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn sʌɾənli ʃaʊɾəd oʊvɝ ðə wɪn ən ðə paʊndɪŋ ə hʊvz. "aɪ kænɑt! moʊst ɪspɛʃli nɑt fɹəm ðə bæk ʌv ə ɡæləpɪŋ hɔɹs. ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑɾ izəli kɪld, ivən wən ðeɪ kən bi sin. wi mʌst ɹʌn, ən hoʊp."

Lan must have asked a question, for Moiraine suddenly shouted over the wind and the pounding of hooves. "I cannot! Most especially not from the back of a galloping horse. They are not easily killed, even when they can be seen. We must run, and hope."

ðeɪ ɡæləp θɹu ə tæɾɝ ə fɑɡ, θɪn ən noʊ haɪɝ ðən ðə hɔɹsəz' niz. klaʊd spɛd θɹu ɪɾ ɪn tu stʃɹaɪdz, ən ɹænd blɪŋkt, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf i hæɾ ɪmædʒən ɪt. ʃʊɹli ðə naɪt wɑz tu koʊl fəɹ fɑɡ. ənʌðɝ pætʃ ə ɹæɡəd ɡɹeɪ wɪsk baɪ ðɛm tə wʌn saɪd, lɑɹdʒɝ ðən ðə fɝst. ɪt hæd bɪn ɡɹoʊɪŋ, əz ɪf ðə mɪst uz fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd. əbʌv ðɛm, ðə dʒɹæɡkɝ skɹimd ɪn ɹeɪdʒ. fɑɡ ɛnvɛləp ðə ɹaɪɾɝz fəɹ ə bɹif moʊmən ən wɑz ɡɔn, keɪm əɡɛn ən vænɪʃt bɪhaɪnd. ði aɪsi mɪs lɛft ə tʃɪl dæmpnəs ɑn ɹændz feɪs ən hænz. ðən ə wɔl ə peɪl ɡɹeɪ lum bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, ən ðeɪ wɝ sʌɾənli ɪnʃɹaʊɾəd. ðə θɪknəs ʌv ɪt mʌfəl ðə saʊn ə ðɛɹ hʊvz tə dʌlnəs, ən ðə kɹaɪz fɹəm oʊvɝhɛd sim tə kʌm θɹu ə wɔl. ɹænd kəɾ oʊnli dʒʌs meɪk aʊt ðə ʃeɪps ʌv ɛɡwin ən tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm.

They galloped through a tatter of fog, thin and no higher than the horses' knees. Cloud sped through it in two strides, and Rand blinked, wondering if he had imagined it. Surely the night was too cold for fog. Another patch of ragged gray whisked by them to one side, larger than the first. It had been growing, as if the mist oozed from the ground. Above them, the Draghkar screamed in rage. Fog enveloped the riders for a brief moment and was gone, came again and vanished behind. The icy mist left a chill dampness on Rand's face and hands. Then a wall of pale gray loomed before them, and they were suddenly enshrouded. The thickness of it muffled the sound of their hooves to dullness, and the cries from overhead seemed to come through a wall. Rand could only just make out the shapes of Egwene and Thom Merrilin on either side of him.

læn dɪd nɑt sloʊ ðɛɹ peɪs. "ðɛɹ ɪz stɪl oʊnli wʌn pleɪs wi kən bi ɡoʊɪŋ," hi kɔld, hɪz vɔɪs saʊndɪŋ hɑloʊ ən dɝɛkʃənləs.

Lan did not slow their pace. "There is still only one place we can be going," he called, his voice sounding hollow and directionless.

"mɹdʒɹɑl ɑɹ slaɪ," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "aɪ wɪl juz ɪts oʊn slaɪnəs əɡɛnst ɪt." ðeɪ ɡæləpt ɑn saɪlənli.

"Myrddraal are sly," Moiraine replied. "I will use its own slyness against it." They galloped on silently.

sleɪɾi mɪst əbskjʊɹd boʊθ skaɪ ən ɡɹaʊnd, soʊ ðət ðə ɹaɪɾɝz, ðɛmsɛlvz tɝn tə ʃædoʊ, əpɪɹd tə floʊt θɹu naɪt klaʊdz. ivən ðə lɛɡz ə ðɛɹ oʊn hɔɹsəz sim tə hæv vænɪʃt.

Slaty mist obscured both sky and ground, so that the riders, themselves turned to shadow, appeared to float through night clouds. Even the legs of their own horses seemed to have vanished.

ɹænd ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, ʃɹɪŋkɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ði aɪsi fɑɡ. noʊɪŋ ðət mɔɪɹeɪn kəd də θɪŋz, ivən siɪŋ əɹ də ðɛm, wɑz wʌn θɪŋ; hævɪŋ ðoʊz θɪŋz liv ɪz skɪn dæmp wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls əɡɛn. hi ɹilaɪzd i wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ɪz bɹɛθ, tu, ən kɔl hɪmsɛlf naɪn kaɪnz ʌv ɪɾiət. hi kəd nɑt ɹaɪɾ ɔl ðə weɪ tə tɛɹən fɛɹi wɪθaʊt bɹiðɪŋ. ʃi hæd juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɑn tæm, ən i simd ɔl ɹaɪt. stɪl, hi hæd tə meɪk hɪmsɛlf lɛt ðət bɹɛθ ɡoʊ ən ɪnheɪl. ði ɛɹ wɑz hɛvi, bʌɾ ɪf koʊldɝ ɪt wɑz ʌðɝwaɪz noʊ dɪfɹən ðən ðəɾ ɑn ɛni ʌðɝ fɑɡi naɪt. hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf ðæt, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i bɪlivd ɪt.

Rand shifted in his saddle, shrinking away from the icy fog. Knowing that Moiraine could do things, even seeing her do them, was one thing; having those things leave his skin damp was something else again. He realized he was holding his breath, too, and called himself nine kinds of idiot. He could not ride all the way to Taren Ferry without breathing. She had used the One Power on Tam, and he seemed all right. Still, he had to make himself let that breath go and inhale. The air was heavy, but if colder it was otherwise no different than that on any other foggy night. He told himself that, but he was not sure he believed it.

læn ɛnkɝɪdʒd əm tə kip kloʊs, naʊ, tə steɪ wɛɹ itʃ kəd si ði aʊtlaɪnz ʌv ʌðɝz ɪn ðət dæmp, fɹɔsti ɡɹeɪnəs. jɛt ðə wɔɹɾɝ stɪl dɪd nɑt slækən ɪz stæljənz dɛd ɹʌn. saɪd baɪ saɪd, læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn lɛd ðə weɪ θɹu ðə fɑɡ əz ɪf ðeɪ kəd si klɪɹli wʌt leɪ əhɛd. ðə ɹɛs kəɾ oʊnli tʃɹʌst ən fɑloʊ. ən hoʊp.

Lan encouraged them to keep close, now, to stay where each could see the outlines of others in that damp, frosty grayness. Yet the Warder still did not slacken his stallion's dead run. Side by side, Lan and Moiraine led the way through the fog as if they could see clearly what lay ahead. The rest could only trust and follow. And hope.

ðə ʃɹɪl kɹaɪz ðət hæd haʊndɪɾ əm feɪɾəd əz ðeɪ ɡæləpt, ən ðən wɝ ɡɔn, bʌt ðət ɡeɪv smɔl kʌmfɝt. fɔɹəst ən fɑɹmhaʊsəz, mun ən ɹoʊd wɝ ʃɹaʊɾɪd ən hɪɾən. dɑɡz stɪl bɑɹkt, hɑloʊ ən dɪstən ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ heɪz, wən ðeɪ pæs fɑɹmz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ʌðɝ saʊn seɪv ðə dʌl dʒɹʌmɪŋ ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz' hʊvz. nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðət fitʃɝləs æʃən fɑɡ tʃeɪnʒd. nʌθɪŋ ɡeɪv ɛni hɪn ə ðə pæsədʒ ə taɪm ɪksɛp ðə ɡɹoʊɪŋ eɪk ɪn θaɪ ən bæk.

The shrill cries that had hounded them faded as they galloped, and then were gone, but that gave small comfort. Forest and farmhouses, moon and road were shrouded and hidden. Dogs still barked, hollow and distant in the gray haze, when they passed farms, but there was no other sound save the dull drumming of their horses' hooves. Nothing in that featureless ashen fog changed. Nothing gave any hint of the passage of time except the growing ache in thigh and back.

ɪt hæd tə hæv bɪn aʊɝz, ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ. hɪz hænz hæd klʌtʃt ɪz ɹeɪnz əntɪl i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i kəd ɹilis ðɛm, ən i wʌndɝɾ ɪf i wəɾ ɛvɝ wɔk pɹɑpɝli əɡɛn. hi ɡlæns bæk oʊnli wʌns. ʃædoʊz ɪn ðə fɑɡ ɹeɪs bɪhaɪn hɪm, bʌɾ i kəd nɑɾ ivən bi sɝɾən ə ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ. əɹ ivən ðət ðeɪ ɹɪli wɝ ɪz fɹɛnz. ðə tʃɪl ən dæmp soʊk θɹu hɪz kloʊk ən koʊɾ ən ʃɝt, soʊkt ɪndə hɪz boʊnz, soʊ ɪt simd. oʊnli ðə ɹʌʃ ʌv ɛɹ pæst ɪz feɪs ən ðə ɡæðɝ ən stʃɹɛtʃ ə ðə hɔɹs bɪniθ ɪm toʊld ɪm i wɑz muvɪŋ əɾ ɔl. ɪt mʌst əv bɪn aʊɝz.

It had to have been hours, Rand was sure. His hands had clutched his reins until he was not sure he could release them, and he wondered if he would ever walk properly again. He glanced back only once. Shadows in the fog raced behind him, but he could not even be certain of their number. Or even that they really were his friends. The chill and damp soaked through his cloak and coat and shirt, soaked into his bones, so it seemed. Only the rush of air past his face and the gather and stretch of the horse beneath him told him he was moving at all. It must have been hours.

"sloʊ," læn kɔl sʌɾənli. "dʒɹɔ ɹeɪn."

"Slow," Lan called suddenly. "Draw rein."

ɹænd wɑz soʊ stɑɹɾəld ðət klaʊd fɔɹs bɪtwin. læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn, fɔɹdʒɪŋ əhɛd fəɹ hæf ə dʌzən stʃɹaɪdz bɪfɔɹ i kəd pʊl ðə bɪɡ ɡɹeɪ tə ə hɔlt ən stɛɹ.

Rand was so startled that Cloud forced between. Lan and Moiraine, forging ahead for half a dozen strides before he could pull the big gray to a halt and stare.

haʊsəz lumd ɪn ðə fɑɡ ɑn ɔl saɪdz, haʊsəz stʃɹeɪnʒli tɔl tə ɹændz aɪ. hi hæd nɛvɝ sin ðɪs pleɪs bɪfɔɹ, bʌɾ i hæɾ ɔfən hɝd dɪskɹɪpʃənz. ðət tælnəs keɪm fɹəm haɪ ɹɛdstoʊn faʊndeɪʃənz, nɛsəsɛɹi wən ðə spɹɪŋ mɛlt ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪs meɪd ðə tɛɹən oʊvɝfloʊ ɪts bæŋks. ðeɪ hæd ɹitʃt tɛɹən fɛɹi.

Houses loomed in the fog on all sides, houses strangely tall to Rand's eye. He had never seen this place before, but he had often heard descriptions. That tallness came from high redstone foundations, necessary when the spring melt in the Mountains of Mist made the Taren overflow its banks. They had reached Taren Ferry.

læn tʃɹɑɾəd ðə blæk wɔɹhɔɹs pæs hɪm. "doʊn bi soʊ iɡɝ, ʃifɝɾɝ."

Lan trotted the black warhorse past him. "Don't be so eager, sheepherder."

dəskɑmfəɾəd, ɹænd fɛl ɪndə pleɪs wɪθaʊɾ ɪkspleɪnɪŋ əz ðə pɑɹɾi muv dipɝ ɪndə ðə vɪlədʒ. hɪz feɪs wɑz hɑt, ən fəɹ ðə moʊmən ðə fɑɡ wɑz wɛlkəm.

Discomfited, Rand fell into place without explaining as the party moved deeper into the village. His face was hot, and for the moment the fog was welcome.

ə loʊn dɔɡ, ənsin ɪn ðə koʊl mɪst, bɑɹkt əɾ əm fjʊɹiəsli, ðən ɹæn əweɪ. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ ə laɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ə wɪndoʊ əz səm ɝli-ɹaɪzɝ stɝd. ʌðɝ ðən ðə dɔɡ, noʊ saʊn seɪv ðə mjuɾɪd klɑps ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz' hʊvz dɪstɝb ðə læst aʊɝ ə ðə naɪt.

A lone dog, unseen in the cold mist, barked at them furiously, then ran away. Here and there a light appeared in a window as some early-riser stirred. Other than the dog, no sound save the muted clops of their horses' hooves disturbed the last hour of the night.

ɹænd hæd mɛt fju pipəl fɹəm tɛɹən fɛɹi. hi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹikɔl wʌt lɪɾəl i nu əbaʊt ðɛm. ðeɪ sɛldəm vɛntʃɝd daʊn ɪndə wʌt ðeɪ kɔld "ðə loʊɝ vɪlədʒəz," wɪð ðɛɹ noʊzɪz ʌp əz ɪf ðeɪ smɛl sʌmθɪŋ bæd. ðə fju hi hæd mɛt bɔɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ neɪmz, laɪk hɪltɑp ən stoʊnboʊt. wʌn ən ɔl, tɛɹən fɛɹi foʊk hæɾ ə ɹɛpjəteɪʃən fəɹ slaɪnəs ən tʃɹɪkɝi. ɪf jə ʃʊk hænz wɪð ə tɛɹən fɛɹi mæn, pipəl sɛd, jə kaʊntəd jəɹ fɪŋɡɝz æftɝwɝdz.

Rand had met few people from Taren Ferry. He tried to recall what little he knew about them. They seldom ventured down into what they called "the lower villages," with their noses up as if they smelled something bad. The few he had met bore strange names, like Hilltop and Stoneboat. One and all, Taren Ferry folk had a reputation for slyness and trickery. If you shook hands with a Taren Ferry man, people said, you counted your fingers afterwards.

læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn stɑp bɪfɔɹ ə tɔl, dɑɹk haʊs ðət lʊkt ɪɡzækli laɪk ɛni ʌðɝ ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ. fɑɡ swɝld ɝaʊn ðə wɔɹɾɝ laɪk smoʊk əz i lɛp fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl ən maʊntəd ðə stɛɹz ðət ɹoʊz tə ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ, əz haɪ əbʌv ðə stʃɹiɾ əz ðɛɹ hɛdz. ət ðə tɑp ə ðə stɛɹz læn hæmɝd wɪð ɪz fɪst ɑn ðə dɔɹ.

Lan and Moiraine stopped before a tall, dark house that looked exactly like any other in the village. Fog swirled around the Warder like smoke as he leaped from his saddle and mounted the stairs that rose to the front door, as high above the street as their heads. At the top of the stairs Lan hammered with his fist on the door.

"aɪ θɔɾ i wɑntəd kwaɪət," mæt mʌɾɝd.

"I thought he wanted quiet," Mat muttered.

lænz paʊndɪŋ wɛn ɑn. ə laɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə wɪndoʊ ʌv ðə nɛks haʊs, ən sʌmwʌn ʃaʊɾəd æŋɡɹəli, bʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝ kɛpt ɑn wɪð ɪz dʒɹʌmɪŋ.

Lan's pounding went on. A light appeared in the window of the next house, and someone shouted angrily, but the Warder kept on with his drumming.

əbɹʌpli ðə dɔɹ wɑz flʌŋ bæk baɪ ə mæn ɪn ə naɪtʃɝt ðət flæpt əbaʊɾ ɪz bɛɹ æŋkəlz. ən ɔɪl læmp ɪn wʌn hæn ɪlumən ə nɛɹoʊ feɪs wɪð pɔɪntəd fitʃɝz. hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ æŋɡɹəli, ðən lɛɾ ɪt steɪ oʊpən əz ɪz hɛd swɪvəl tə teɪk ɪn ðə fɑɡ, aɪz bʌlʒɪŋ. "wʌts ðɪs?" hi sɛd. "wʌts ðɪs?" tʃɪl ɡɹeɪ tɛnʒɹəlz kɝld ɪndə ðə dɔɹweɪ, ən i hɝidli stɛp bæk əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm.

Abruptly the door was flung back by a man in a nightshirt that flapped about his bare ankles. An oil lamp in one hand illumined a narrow face with pointed features. He opened his mouth angrily, then let it stay open as his head swiveled to take in the fog, eyes bulging. "What's this?" he said. "What's this?" Chill gray tendrils curled into the doorway, and he hurriedly stepped back away from them.

"mæstɝ haɪtaʊɝ," læn sɛd. "dʒʌs ðə mæn aɪ nid. wi wɑnə kɹɔs oʊvɝ ɑn jəɹ fɛɹi."

"Master Hightower," Lan said. "Just the man I need. We want to cross over on your ferry."

"hi nɛvɝ ivən sɔ ə haɪ taʊɝ," mæt snɪkɝd. ɹænd meɪd ʃʌʃɪŋ moʊʃənz əɾ ɪz fɹɛnd. ðə ʃɑɹp-feɪs fɛloʊ ɹeɪzd ɪz læmp haɪɝ ən pɪɹd daʊn əɾ əm səspɪʃəsli.

"He never even saw a high tower," Mat snickered. Rand made shushing motions at his friend. The sharp-faced fellow raised his lamp higher and peered down at them suspiciously.

æftɝ ə mɪnət mæstɝ haɪtaʊɝ sɛd kɹɑsli, "ðə fɛɹi ɡoʊz oʊvɝ ɪn deɪlaɪt. nɑɾ ɪn ðə naɪt. nɑɾ ɛvɝ. ən nɑɾ ɪn ðɪs fɑɡ, niðɝ. kʌm bæk wən ðə sʌnz ʌp ən ðə fɑɡz ɡɔn."

After a minute Master Hightower said crossly, "The ferry goes over in daylight. Not in the night. Not ever. And not in this fog, neither. Come back when the sun's up and the fog's gone."

hi stɑɹɾəd tə tɝn əweɪ, bʌt læn kɑɾ ɪz ɹɪst. ðə fɛɹimən oʊpən ɪz maʊθ æŋɡɹəli. ɡoʊld ɡlɪntɪɾ ɪn ðə læmplaɪɾ əz ðə wɔɹɾɝ kaʊntəɾ aʊt kɔɪnz wʌn baɪ wʌn ɪndə ði ʌðɝz pɑm. haɪtaʊɝ lɪkt ɪz lɪps əz ðə kɔɪnz klɪŋkt, ən baɪ ɪntʃəz ɪz hɛd muv kloʊsɝ tə hɪz hænd, əz ɪf i kəd nɑt bɪliv wʌɾ i wɑz siɪŋ.

He started to turn away, but Lan caught his wrist. The ferryman opened his mouth angrily. Gold glinted in the lamplight as the Warder counted out coins one by one into the other's palm. Hightower licked his lips as the coins clinked, and by inches his head moved closer to his hand, as if he could not believe what he was seeing.

"æn əz mʌtʃ əɡɛn," læn sɛd, "wɛn wəɹ seɪfli ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. bʌt wi liv naʊ."

"And as much again," Lan said, "when we are safely on the other side. But we leave now."
