They took places around the table, with Moiraine at the head and Lan at the foot, and for a while everyone was too busy filling their plates for talk. It might not have been a feast, but after close to a week of flatbread and dried meat, it tasted like one.

æftɝ ə taɪm, mɔɪɹeɪn æskt, "wʌt dɪd jə lɝn ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum?" naɪvz ən fɔɹks stɪld, səspɛndəɾ ɪn mɪdɛɹ, ən ɔl aɪz tɝn tə ðə wɔɹɾɝ.

After a time, Moiraine asked, "What did you learn in the common room?" Knives and forks stilled, suspended in midair, and all eyes turned to the Warder.

"lɪɾəl ðæts ɡʊd," læn ɹɪplaɪd. "eɪvɪn wɑz ɹaɪt, ət list əz fɑɹ əz tɔk əz ɪt. ðəɹ wɑz ə bæɾəl ɪn ɡildən, ən lɑɡən wɑz ðə vɪktɝ. ə dʌzən dɪfɹən stɔɹiz ɑɹ floʊɾɪŋ əbaʊt, bʌt ðeɪ ɔl əɡɹi ɑn ðæt."

"Little that's good," Lan replied. "Avin was right, at least as far as talk has it. There was a battle in Ghealdan, and Logain was the victor. A dozen different stories are floating about, but they all agree on that."

lɑɡən? ðət mʌs bi ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. ɪt wɑz ðə fɝs taɪm ɹænd hæd hɝɾ ə neɪm pʊt tə ðə mæn. læn saʊndəɾ ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf i nu hɪm.

Logain? That must be the false Dragon. It was the first time Rand had heard a name put to the man. Lan sounded almost as if he knew him.

"ði ɛɛs sədaɪ?" mɔɪɹeɪn æskt kwaɪətli, ən læn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

"The Aes Sedai?" Moiraine asked quietly, and Lan shook his head.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ. səm seɪ ðeɪ wɝ ɔl kɪld, səm seɪ nʌn." hi snɔɹɾɪd. "sʌm ivən seɪ ðeɪ wɛn oʊvɝ tə lɑɡən. ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ ɹɪlaɪəbəl, ən aɪ dɪd nɑt kɛɹ tə ʃoʊ tu mʌtʃ ɪntʃɹəst."

"I don't know. Some say they were all killed, some say none." He snorted. "Some even say they went over to Logain. There's nothing reliable, and I did not care to show too much interest."

"jɛs," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "lɪɾəl ðəɾ ɪz ɡʊd." wɪð ə dip bɹɛθ ʃi bɹɔɾ əɹ ətɛnʃən bæk tə ðə teɪbəl. "ænd wʌɾ ʌv əɹ oʊn sɝkəmstænsəz?"

"Yes," Moiraine said. "Little that is good." With a deep breath she brought her attention back to the table. "And what of our own circumstances?"

"ðɛɹ, ðə nuz ɪz bɛɾɝ. noʊ ɑd hæpənɪŋz, noʊ stʃɹeɪnʒɝz ɝaʊn u maɪt bi mɹdʒɹɑl, sɝɾənli noʊ tʃɹɑləks. ən ðə waɪtkloʊks ɑɹ bɪzi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk tʃɹʌbəl fəɹ ɡʌvɝnɝ eɪɾən kəz i woʊn koʊɑpɝeɪt wɪð ðɛm. ðəl nɑɾ ivən noʊɾəs əs ənlɛs wi ædvɝtaɪz aʊɝsɛlvz."

"There, the news is better. No odd happenings, no strangers around who might be Myrddraal, certainly no Trollocs. And the Whitecloaks are busy trying to make trouble for Governor Adan because he won't cooperate with them. They will not even notice us unless we advertise ourselves."

"ɡʊd," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ðæɾ əɡɹiz wɪð wʌt ðə bæθ meɪd sɛd. ɡɑsəp dʌz əv ɪts pɔɪns. naʊ," ʃi ədʒɹɛs ði ɪntaɪɝ kʌmpəni, "wi hæv ə lɔŋ dʒɝni stɪl əhɛɾ ʌv ʌs, bʌt ðə læst wik əz nɑt bɪn izi, iðɝ, soʊ aɪ pɹəpoʊz tə ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ tənaɪɾ ən təmɑɹoʊ naɪt, ən liv ɝli ðə fɑloʊɪŋ mɔɹnɪŋ." ɔl ðə jʌŋɡɝ foʊk ɡɹɪnd; ə sɪɾi fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. mɔɪɹeɪn smaɪld, bʌt ʃi stɪl sɛd, "wʌt dʌz mæstɝ ænʒɹə seɪ tə ðæt?"

"Good," Moiraine said. "That agrees with what the bath maid said. Gossip does have its points. Now," she addressed the entire company, "we have a long journey still ahead of us, but the last week has not been easy, either, so I propose to remain here tonight and tomorrow night, and leave early the following morning." All the younger folk grinned; a city for the first time. Moiraine smiled, but she still said, "What does Master Andra say to that?"

læn aɪd ðə ɡɹɪnɪŋ feɪsəz flætli. "wɛl ɪnʌf, ɪf ðeɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ aɪv toʊld əm fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ."

Lan eyed the grinning faces flatly. "Well enough, if they remember what I've told them for a change."

tɑm snɔɹɾɪd θɹu hɪz mʌstæʃɪz. "ðiz kʌntʃɹi foʊk lus ɪn ə . . . ə sɪɾi." hi snɔɹɾɪd əɡɛn ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

Thom snorted through his mustaches. "These country folk loose in a . . . a city." He snorted again and shook his head.

wɪð ðə kɹaʊɾɪŋ ət ði ɪn ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli θɹi ɹumz tə bi hæd, wʌn fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn ən ɛɡwin, ən tu tə teɪk ðə mɛn. ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf ʃɛɹɪŋ wɪð læn ən tɑm, ɑn ðə fɔɹθ flɔɹ ət ðə bæk, kloʊs ʌp ʌndɝ ði oʊvɝhæŋɪŋ ivz, wɪð ə sɪŋɡəl smɔl wɪndoʊ ðəɾ oʊvɝlʊk ðə steɪbliɑɹd. fʊl naɪt hæd fɔlən, ən laɪt fɹəm ði ɪn meɪɾ ə pul aʊtsaɪd. ɪt wɑz ə smɔl ɹum tə bɪɡɪn, ən ən ɛkstʃɹə bɛd sɛɾ ʌp fəɹ tɑm meɪɾ ɪt smɔlɝ, ðoʊ ɔl θɹi wɝ nɛɹoʊ. ən hɑɹd, ɹænd faʊnd wən i θɹu hɪmsɛlf daʊn ɑn hɪz. dɛfənətli nɑt ðə bɛst ɹum.

With the crowding at the inn there were only three rooms to be had, one for Moiraine and Egwene, and two to take the men. Rand found himself sharing with Lan and Thom, on the fourth floor at the back, close up under the overhanging eaves, with a single small window that overlooked the stableyard. Full night had fallen, and light from the inn made a pool outside. It was a small room to begin, and an extra bed set up for Thom made it smaller, though all three were narrow. And hard, Rand found when he threw himself down on his. Definitely not the best room.

tɑm steɪɾ oʊnli lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ənkeɪs ɪz fluɾ ən hɑɹp, ðən lɛft ɔlɹɛɾi pɹæktəsɪŋ ɡɹæn poʊzəz. læn wɛnt wɪð hɪm.

Thom stayed only long enough to uncase his flute and harp, then left already practicing grand poses. Lan went with him.

ɪt wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ, ɹænd θɔɾ əz i ʃɪftəɾ ənkʌmftəbli ɑn ðə bɛd. ə wik əɡoʊ hi wʊɾə bɪn daʊnstɛɹz laɪk ə fɔlɪŋ ɹɑk fəɹ dʒʌs ðə tʃæns i maɪt si ə ɡlimən pɝfɔɹm, fəɹ dʒʌs ðə ɹumɝ ʌv ɪt. bʌɾ i hæd hɝd tɑm tɛl ɪz stɔɹiz ɛvɹi naɪt fəɹ ə wik, ən tɑm wəd bi ðəɹ təmɑɹoʊ naɪt, ən ðə nɛkst, ən ðə hɑt bæθ hæd lusən kɪŋks ɪn mʌsəlz ðəɾ i hæd θɔt wəd bi ðəɹ fɝɛvɝ, ən ɪz fɝs hɑt mil ɪn ə wik uz lɛθɝdʒi ɪndə hɪm. slipəli hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf læn ɹɪli dɪd noʊ ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən, lɑɡən. ə mʌfəld ʃaʊt keɪm fɹəm bɛləstɛɹz, ðə kɑmən ɹum ɡɹiɾɪŋ tɑmz ɝaɪvəl, bʌt ɹænd wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi əslip.

It was strange, Rand thought as he shifted uncomfortably on the bed. A week ago he would have been downstairs like a falling rock for just the chance he might see a gleeman perform, for just the rumor of it. But he had heard Thom tell his stories every night for a week, and Thom would be there tomorrow night, and the next, and the hot bath had loosened kinks in muscles that he had thought would be there forever, and his first hot meal in a week oozed lethargy into him. Sleepily he wondered if Lan really did know the false Dragon, Logain. A muffled shout came from belowstairs, the common room greeting Thom's arrival, but Rand was already asleep.

ðə stoʊn hɔlweɪ wɑz dɪm ən ʃæɾoʊi, ən ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ɹænd. hi kəd nɑt tɛl wɛɹ ðə laɪt keɪm fɹʌm, wʌt lɪɾəl ðəɹ wɑz ʌv ɪt; ðə ɡɹeɪ wɔlz wɝ bɛɹ ə kændəlz əɹ læmps, nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl tə əkaʊn fəɹ ðə feɪnt ɡloʊ ðət sim tə dʒʌs bi ðɛɹ. ði ɛɹ wɑz stɪl ən dæŋk, ən sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə dɪstəns wɔɾɝ dʒɹɪpt wɪð ə stɛɾi, hɑloʊ plɑŋk. wɛɹɛvɝ ðɪs wɑz, ɪt wɑz nɑt ði ɪn. fɹaʊnɪŋ, hi ɹʌbd əɾ ɪz fɔɹhɛd. ɪn? hɪz hɛd hɝt, ən θɔts wɝ hɑɹd tə hoʊld ɑn tə. ðəɹ hæd bɪn sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt . . . ən ɪn? ɪt wɑz ɡɔn, wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz.

The stone hallway was dim and shadowy, and empty except for Rand. He could not tell where the light came from, what little there was of it; the gray walls were bare of candles or lamps, nothing at all to account for the faint glow that seemed to just be there. The air was still and dank, and somewhere in the distance water dripped with a steady, hollow plonk. Wherever this was, it was not the inn. Frowning, he rubbed at his forehead. Inn? His head hurt, and thoughts were hard to hold on to. There had been something about . . . an inn? It was gone, whatever it was.

hi lɪkt ɪz lɪps ən wɪʃt i hæd sʌmθɪŋ tə dʒɹɪŋk. hi wɑz ɑfli θɝsti, dʒɹaɪ-æz-dʌs θɝsti. ɪt wɑz ðə dʒɹɪpɪŋ saʊn ðət dɪsaɪɾɪd hɪm. wɪð nʌθɪŋ tə tʃuz baɪ ɪksɛpt ɪz θɝst, hi stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðət stɛɾi plɑŋk - plɑŋk - plɑŋk.

He licked his lips and wished he had something to drink. He was awfully thirsty, dry-as-dust thirsty. It was the dripping sound that decided him. With nothing to choose by except his thirst, he started toward that steady plonk - plonk - plonk.

ðə hɔlweɪ stʃɹɛtʃt ɑn, wɪθaʊɾ ɛni kɹɔsɪŋ kɔɹəɾɝ ən wɪθaʊt ðə slaɪɾəst tʃeɪnʒ ɪn əpɪɹəns. ði oʊnli fitʃɝz əɾ ɔl wɝ ðə ɹʌf dɔɹz sɛɾ ət ɹɛɡjəlɝ ɪntɝvəlz ɪn pɛɹz, wʌn ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə hɔl, ðə wʊd splɪntɝɾ ən dʒɹaɪ dɪspaɪt ðə dæmp ɪn ði ɛɹ. ðə ʃædoʊz ɹəsiɾəd əhɛɾ ə hɪm, steɪɪŋ ðə seɪm, ən ðə dʒɹɪpɪŋ nɛvɝ keɪm ɛni kloʊsɝ. æftɝ ə lɔŋ taɪm i dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tʃɹaɪ wʌn ə ðoʊz dɔɹz. ɪɾ oʊpən izəli, ən i stɛp θɹu ɪndə ə ɡɹɪm, stoʊn-wɔl tʃeɪmbɝ.

The hallway stretched on, without any crossing corridor and without the slightest change in appearance. The only features at all were the rough doors set at regular intervals in pairs, one on either side of the hall, the wood splintered and dry despite the damp in the air. The shadows receded ahead of him, staying the same, and the dripping never came any closer. After a long time he decided to try one of those doors. It opened easily, and he stepped through into a grim, stone-walled chamber.

wʌn wɔl oʊpən ɪn ə sɪɹiz ʌv ɑɹtʃəz ɑntu ə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn bælkəni, ən bɪɑn ðət wɑz ə skaɪ sətʃ əz i hæd nɛvɝ sin. stʃɹieɪɾɪd klaʊdz ɪn blæks ən ɡɹeɪz, ɹɛdz ən ɔɹənʒəz, stʃɹim baɪ əz ɪf stɔɹm wɪnz dʒɹoʊv ðɛm, wivɪŋ ən ɪntɝwivɪŋ ɛnləsli. noʊ wʌn kəɾ ɛvɝ əv sin ə skaɪ laɪk ðæt; ɪt kəd nɑɾ ɪɡzɪst.

One wall opened in a series of arches onto a gray stone balcony, and beyond that was a sky such as he had never seen. Striated clouds in blacks and grays, reds and oranges, streamed by as if storm winds drove them, weaving and interweaving endlessly. No one could ever have seen a sky like that; it could not exist.

hi pʊld ɪz aɪz əweɪ fɹəm ðə bælkəni, bʌt ðə ɹɛst ə ðə ɹum wɑz noʊ bɛɾɝ. ɑd kɝvz ən pəkjuljɝ æŋɡəlz, əz ɪf ðə tʃeɪmbɝ hæd bɪn mɛltəɾ ɔlmoʊs hæfəzɝdli aʊɾ ə ðə stoʊn, ən kɑləmz ðət sim tə ɡɹoʊ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪ flɔɹ. fleɪmz ɹɔɹɾ ɑn ðə hɑɹθ laɪk ə fɔɹdʒ-faɪɝ wɪð ðə bɛloʊz pʌmpɪŋ, bʌt ɡeɪv noʊ hit. stʃɹeɪnʒ oʊvəl stoʊnz meɪd ðə faɪɝpleɪs; ðeɪ dʒʌs lʊk laɪk stoʊnz, wɛt-slɪk dɪspaɪt ðə faɪɝ, wən i lʊk stʃɹeɪɾ ət ðɛm, bʌt wən i ɡlɪmpst əm fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ ðeɪ sim tə bi feɪsəz ɪnstɛd, ðə feɪsəz ə mɛn ən wɪmən ɹaɪðɪŋ ɪn æŋɡwɪʃ, skɹimɪŋ saɪlənli. ðə haɪ-bæk tʃɛɹz ən ðə pɑlɪʃt teɪbəl ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum wɝ pɝfəkli ɔɹɾənɛɹi, bʌt ðəɾ ɪn ɪtsɛlf ɛmfəsaɪz ðə ɹɛst. ə sɪŋɡəl mɪɹɝ hʌŋ ɑn ðə wɔl, bʌt ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɔɹɾənɛɹi əɾ ɔl. wən i lʊkt əɾ ɪɾ i sɔ oʊnli ə blɝ wɛɹ ɪz ɹəflɛkʃən ʃəɾ əv bɪn. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls ɪn ðə ɹum wɑz ʃoʊn tʃɹu, bʌt nɑt hɪm.

He pulled his eyes away from the balcony, but the rest of the room was no better. Odd curves and peculiar angles, as if the chamber had been melted almost haphazardly out of the stone, and columns that seemed to grow out of the gray floor. Flames roared on the hearth like a forge-fire with the bellows pumping, but gave no heat. Strange oval stones made the fireplace; they just looked like stones, wet-slick despite the fire, when he looked straight at them, but when he glimpsed them from the corner of his eye they seemed to be faces instead, the faces of men and women writhing in anguish, screaming silently. The high-backed chairs and the polished table in the middle of the room were perfectly ordinary, but that in itself emphasized the rest. A single mirror hung on the wall, but that was not ordinary at all. When he looked at it he saw only a blur where his reflection should have been. Everything else in the room was shown true, but not him.

ə mæn stʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. hi hæd nɑt noʊɾəst ðə mæn wən i fɝs keɪm ɪn. ɪf i hæd nɑt noʊn ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl, hi wʊɾə sɛd noʊ wʌn hæd bɪn ðəɹ əntɪl i æktʃəli  lʊkt ət ðə mæn. dʒɹɛst ɪn dɑɹk kloʊðz ʌv ə faɪn kʌt, hi simd ɪn ðə pɹaɪm ə hɪz mətʃʊɹəɾi, ən ɹænd səpoʊzd wʊɾə əv faʊn ɪm ɡʊd-lʊkɪŋ.

A man stood in front of the fireplace. He had not noticed the man when he first came in. If he had not known it was impossible, he would have said no one had been there until he actually looked at the man. Dressed in dark clothes of a fine cut, he seemed in the prime of his maturity, and Rand supposed women would have found him good-looking.

"wʌns mɔɹ wi mit feɪs-tə-feɪs," ðə mæn sɛɾ ænd, dʒʌs fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, hɪz maʊθ ən aɪz bɪkeɪm oʊpənɪŋz ɪndə ɛnləs kævɝnz ə fleɪm.

"Once more we meet face-to-face," the man said and, just for an instant, his mouth and eyes became openings into endless caverns of flame.

wɪð ə jɛl ɹænd hɝl hɪmsɛlf bækwɝdz aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum, soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ i stʌmbəld əkɹɔs ðə hɔl ən bæŋd ɪndə ðə dɔɹ ðɛɹ, nɑkɪŋ ɪɾ oʊpən. hi twɪstəɾ ən ɡɹæbd ət ðə dɔɹhændəl tə kip fɹəm fɔlɪŋ tə ðə flɔɹ - ən faʊn hɪmsɛlf stɛɹɪŋ waɪd-aɪɾ ɪndə ə stoʊn ɹum wɪð ən ɪmpɑsəbəl skaɪ θɹu ði ɑɹtʃəz liɾɪŋ tə ə bælkəni, ən ə faɪɝpleɪs. . . .

With a yell Rand hurled himself backwards out of the room, so hard that he stumbled across the hall and banged into the door there, knocking it open. He twisted and grabbed at the doorhandle to keep from falling to the floor - and found himself staring wide-eyed into a stone room with an impossible sky through the arches leading to a balcony, and a fireplace. . . .

"ju kænɑt ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm mi ðəɾ izəli," ðə mæn sɛd.

"You cannot get away from me that easily," the man said.

ɹænd twɪstəd, skɹæmbəlɪŋ bæk aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɪɡeɪn ɪz fit wɪθaʊt sloʊɪŋ daʊn. ðɪs taɪm ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kɔɹəɾɝ. hi fɹoʊz hæf kɹaʊtʃt nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə pɑlɪʃt teɪbəl, ən lʊkt ət ðə mæn baɪ ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən lʊkɪŋ ət ðə faɪɝpleɪs stoʊnz, əɹ ət ðə skaɪ.

Rand twisted, scrambling back out of the room, trying to regain his feet without slowing down. This time there was no corridor. He froze half crouched not far from the polished table, and looked at the man by the fireplace. It was better than looking at the fireplace stones, or at the sky.

"ðɪs ɪz ə dʒɹim," hi sɛɾ əz i stʃɹeɪɾənd. bɪhaɪn ɪm i hɝd ðə klɪk ə ðə dɔɹ kloʊzɪŋ. "ɪts səm kaɪndə naɪtmɛɹ." hi ʃʌɾ ɪz aɪz, θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt weɪkɪŋ ʌp. wən i wɑz ə tʃaɪl ðə wɪzdəm hæd sɛɾ ɪf jə kəd də ðəɾ ɪn ə naɪtmɛɹ, ɪt wəd ɡoʊ əweɪ. ðə . . . wɪzdəm? wʌt? ɪf oʊnli hɪz θɔts wəd stɑp slaɪɾɪŋ əweɪ. ɪf oʊnli hɪz hɛd wəd stɑp hɝɾɪŋ, ðən i kəd θɪŋk stʃɹeɪt.

"This is a dream," he said as he straightened. Behind him he heard the click of the door closing. "It's some kind of nightmare." He shut his eyes, thinking about waking up. When he was a child the Wisdom had said if you could do that in a nightmare, it would go away. The . . . Wisdom? What? If only his thoughts would stop sliding away. If only his head would stop hurting, then he could think straight.

hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz əɡɛn. ðə ɹum wɑz stɪl əz ɪt hæd bɪn, ðə bælkəni, ðə skaɪ. ðə mæn baɪ ðə faɪɝpleɪs.

He opened his eyes again. The room was still as it had been, the balcony, the sky. The man by the fireplace.

"ɪz ɪɾ ə dʒɹim?" ðə mæn sɛd. "dʌz ɪt mæɾɝ?" wʌns əɡɛn, fəɹ ə moʊmənt, hɪz maʊθ ən aɪz bɪkeɪm piifoʊlz ɪndə ə fɝnəs ðət sim tə stʃɹɛtʃ fɝɛvɝ. hɪz vɔɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ; hi dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs ɪt hæpənɪŋ əɾ ɔl.

"Is it a dream?" the man said. "Does it matter?" Once again, for a moment, his mouth and eyes became peepholes into a furnace that seemed to stretch forever. His voice did not change; he did not seem to notice it happening at all.

ɹænd dʒʌmpt ə lɪɾəl ðɪs taɪm, bʌɾ i mænədʒ tə kip fɹəm jɛlɪŋ. ðɪs ɪz ə dʒɹim. ɪts tə bi. ɔl ðə seɪm, hi stɛp bækwɝdz ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə dɔɹ, nɛvɝ teɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz ɔf ðə fɛloʊ baɪ ðə faɪɝ, ən tʃɹaɪd ðə hændəl. ɪt dɪd nɑt muv; ðə dɔɹ wɑz lɑkt.

Rand jumped a little this time, but he managed to keep from yelling. This is a dream. It has to be. All the same, he stepped backwards all the way to the door, never taking his eyes off the fellow by the fire, and tried the handle. It did not move; the door was locked.

"ju sim θɝsti," ðə mæn baɪ ðə faɪɝ sɛd. "dʒɹɪŋk."

"You seem thirsty," the man by the fire said. "Drink."

ɑn ðə teɪbəl wɑz ə ɡɑblət, ʃaɪnɪŋ ɡoʊld ən ɔɹnəmɛntɪd wɪð ɹubiz ən æmɛθɪsts. ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ. hi wɪʃt i kəd stɑp dʒʌmpɪŋ. ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə dʒɹim. hɪz maʊθ fɛlt laɪk dʌst.

On the table was a goblet, shining gold and ornamented with rubies and amethysts. It had not been there before. He wished he could stop jumping. It was only a dream. His mouth felt like dust.

"aɪ æm, ə lɪɾəl," hi sɛd, pɪkɪŋ ʌp ðə ɡɑblət. ðə mæn lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪntɛnli, wʌn hæn ɑn ðə bæk ʌv ə tʃɛɹ, wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm. ðə smɛl ə spaɪst waɪn dʒɹoʊv hoʊm tə ɹænd dʒʌs haʊ θɝsti hi wɑz, əz ɪf i hæd hæd nʌθɪŋ tə dʒɹɪŋk ɪn deɪz. hæv aɪ?

"I am, a little," he said, picking up the goblet. The man leaned forward intently, one hand on the back of a chair, watching him. The smell of spiced wine drove home to Rand just how thirsty he was, as if he had had nothing to drink in days. Have I?

wɪð ðə waɪn hæfweɪ tə hɪz maʊθ, hi stɑpt. wɪspɝz ə smoʊk wɝ ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə tʃɛɹbæk bɪtwin ðə mænz fɪŋɡɝz. ən ðoʊz aɪz wɑtʃt ɪm soʊ ʃɑɹpli, flɪkɝɪŋ ɹæpədli ɪn ən aʊɾ ə fleɪmz.

With the wine halfway to his mouth, he stopped. Whispers of smoke were rising from the chairback between the man's fingers. And those eyes watched him so sharply, flickering rapidly in and out of flames.

ɹænd lɪkt ɪz lɪps ən pʊt ðə waɪn bæk ɑn ðə teɪbəl, ənteɪstəd. "aɪm nɑɾ əz θɝsti əz aɪ θɔt." ðə mæn stʃɹeɪɾənd əbɹʌpli, hɪz feɪs wɪθaʊɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən. hɪz dɪsəpɔɪnmənt kəd nɑɾ əv bɪn mɔɹ pleɪn ɪf i hæd kɝst. ɹænd wʌndɝd wʌt wɑz ɪn ðə waɪn. bʌt ðət wɑz ə stupəd kwɛstʃən, ʌv kɔɹs. ðɪs wɑz ɔl ə dʒɹim. ðən waɪ woʊn ɪt stɑp? "wʌt dʒju wɑnt?" hi dɪmændəd. "hu ɑɹ ju?"

Rand licked his lips and put the wine back on the table, untasted. "I'm not as thirsty as I thought." The man straightened abruptly, his face without expression. His disappointment could not have been more plain if he had cursed. Rand wondered what was in the wine. But that was a stupid question, of course. This was all a dream. Then why won't it stop? "What do you want?" he demanded. "Who are you?"

fleɪmz ɹoʊz ɪn ðə mænz aɪz ən maʊθ; ɹænd θɔɾ i kəd hɪɹ əm ɹɔɹ. "sʌm kɔl mi bælzəmən."

Flames rose in the man's eyes and mouth; Rand thought he could hear them roar. "Some call me Ba'alzamon."

ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf feɪsɪŋ ðə dɔɹ, dʒɝkɪŋ fɹæntəkəli ət ðə hændəl. ɔl θɔɾ ə dʒɹimz hæd vænɪʃt. ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ðə dɔɹhændəl wəd nɑt bʌdʒ, bʌɾ i kɛp twɪstɪŋ.

Rand found himself facing the door, jerking frantically at the handle. All thought of dreams had vanished. The Dark One. The doorhandle would not budge, but he kept twisting.

"ɑɹ jə ðə wʌn?" bælzəmən sɛd sʌɾənli. "ju kænɑt haɪɾ ɪt fɹəm mi fɝɛvɝ. jə kænɑɾ ivən haɪd jɝsɛlf fɹəm mi, nɑɾ ɑn ðə haɪəs maʊntən əɹ ɪn ðə dipəs keɪv. aɪ noʊ jə daʊn tə ðə smɔləs hɛɹ."

"Are you the one?" Ba'alzamon said suddenly. "You cannot hide it from me forever. You cannot even hide yourself from me, not on the highest mountain or in the deepest cave. I know you down to the smallest hair."

ɹænd tɝn tə feɪs ðə mæn - tə feɪs bælzəmən. hi swɑloʊd hɑɹd. ə naɪtmɛɹ. hi ɹitʃt bæk tə ɡɪv ðə dɔɹ-hændəl wʌn læs pʊl, ðən stʊɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪɾɝ.

Rand turned to face the man - to face Ba'alzamon. He swallowed hard. A nightmare. He reached back to give the door-handle one last pull, then stood up straighter.

"ɑɹ jə ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɡlɔɹi?" bælzəmən sɛd. "paʊɝ? dɪd ðeɪ tɛl jə ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld wəd sɝv ju? wʌt ɡlɔɹi əɹ paʊɝ ɪz ðəɹ fəɹ ə pʌpət? ðə stʃɹɪŋz ðət muv juv bɪn sɛntʃɝiz wivɪŋ. jəɹ fɑðɝ wɑz tʃoʊzən baɪ ðə waɪt taʊɝ, laɪk ə stæljən ɹoʊpt ən lɛd tə hɪz bɪznəs. jəɹ mʌðɝ wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə bɹud mɛɹ tə ðɛɹ plænz. ən ðoʊz plænz lɛd tə jəɹ dɛθ."

"Are you expecting glory?" Ba'alzamon said. "Power? Did they tell you the Eye of the World would serve you? What glory or power is there for a puppet? The strings that move you have been centuries weaving. Your father was chosen by the White Tower, like a stallion roped and led to his business. Your mother was no more than a brood mare to their plans. And those plans lead to your death."

ɹændz hænz nɑɾɪd ɪn fɪsts. "maɪ fɑðɝ ɪz ə ɡʊd mæn, ən maɪ mʌðɝ wɑz ə ɡʊd wʊmən. doʊn jə tɔk əbaʊt ðɛm!"

Rand's hands knotted in fists. "My father is a good man, and my mother was a good woman. Don't you talk about them!"

ðə fleɪmz læft. "soʊ ðəɹ ɪz səm spɪɹəɾ ɪn jə æftɝ ɔl. pɝhæps jə ɑɹ ðə wʌn. lɪɾəl ɡʊɾ ɪɾəl də ju. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wɪl juz jə əntɪl jə ɑɹ kənsumd, dʒʌst əz dɑviən wɑz juzd, ən jʊɹiən stoʊnboʊ, ən ɡɛɹ əmɑlɑsən, ən ɹɑoʊlɪn dɑɹksbeɪn. dʒʌst əz lɑɡən ɪz biɪŋ juzd. juzd əntɪl ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ lɛft ə ju."

The flames laughed. "So there is some spirit in you after all. Perhaps you are the one. Little good it will do you. The Amyrlin Seat will use you until you are consumed, just as Davian was used, and Yurian Stonebow, and Guaire Amalasan, and Raolin Darksbane. Just as Logain is being used. Used until there is nothing left of you."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ. . . ." ɹænd swʌŋ ɪz hɛd fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd. ðət wʌn moʊmən ə klɪɹ θɪŋkɪŋ, bɔɹn ɪn æŋɡɝ, wɑz ɡɔn. ivən əz i ɡɹoʊp fəɹ ɪɾ əɡɛn i kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ haʊ hi hæd ɹitʃt ɪt ðə fɝs taɪm. hɪz θɔts spʌn ɝaʊn ən ɝaʊnd. hi sizd wʌn laɪk ə ɹæft ɪn ðə wɝlpul. hi fɔɹs ðə wɝdz aʊt, hɪz vɔɪs stʃɹɛŋθənɪŋ ðə fɝðɝ i wɛnt. "ju . . . ɑɹ baʊnd . . . ɪn ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. jə ən ɔl ðə fɔɹseɪkən . . . baʊn baɪ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ əntɪl ði ɛn ə taɪm."

"I don't know. . . ." Rand swung his head from side to side. That one moment of clear thinking, born in anger, was gone. Even as he groped for it again he could not remember how he had reached it the first time. His thoughts spun around and around. He seized one like a raft in the whirlpool. He forced the words out, his voice strengthening the further he went. "You . . . are bound . . . in Shayol Ghul. You and all the Forsaken . . . bound by the Creator until the end of time."

"ði ɛn ə taɪm?" bælzəmən mɑkt. "ju lɪv laɪk ə biɾəl ʌndɝ ə ɹɑk, ən jə θɪŋk jəɹ slaɪm ɪz ðə junəvɝs. ðə dɛθ ə taɪm wɪl bɹɪŋ mi paʊɝ sətʃ əz jə kəd nɑt dʒɹim ʌv, wɝm."

"The end of time?" Ba'alzamon mocked. "You live like a beetle under a rock, and you think your slime is the universe. The death of time will bring me power such as you could not dream of, worm."

"ju ɑɹ baʊnd - "

"You are bound - "

"ful, aɪ hæv nɛvɝ bɪn baʊnd!" ðə faɪɝz ə hɪz feɪs ɹɔɹd soʊ hɑt ðət ɹænd stɛp bæk, ʃɛltɝɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz hænz. ðə swɛɾ ɑn ɪz pɑmz dʒɹaɪd fɹəm ðə hit. "aɪ stʊɾ ət luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝz ʃoʊldɝ wən i dɪd ðə did ðət neɪm hɪm. ɪt wɑz aɪ hu toʊld ɪm tə kɪl ɪz waɪf, ən ɪz tʃɪlʒɹən, ən ɔl ɪz blʌd, ən ɛvɹi lɪvɪŋ pɝsən u lʌvd ɪm əɹ hum i lʌvd. ɪt wɑz aɪ hu ɡeɪv ɪm ðə moʊmən ə sænəɾi tə noʊ wʌɾ i hæd dʌn. hæv jə ɛvɝ hɝɾ ə mæn skɹim ɪz soʊl əweɪ, wɝm? hi cʊɾə stʃɹʌk ət mi, ðɛn. hi kəd nɑɾ əv wʌn, bʌɾ i kəɾ əv tʃɹaɪd. ɪnstɛɾ i kɔl daʊn ɪz pɹɛʃəs wʌn paʊɝ əpɑn hɪmsɛlf, soʊ mʌtʃ ðət ði ɝθ splɪɾ oʊpən ən ɹɪɹɾ ʌp dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊn tə mɑɹk ɪz tum.

"Fool, I have never been bound!" The fires of his face roared so hot that Rand stepped back, sheltering behind his hands. The sweat on his palms dried from the heat. "I stood at Lews Therin Kinslayer's shoulder when he did the deed that named him. It was I who told him to kill his wife, and his children, and all his blood, and every living person who loved him or whom he loved. It was I who gave him the moment of sanity to know what he had done. Have you ever heard a man scream his soul away, worm? He could have struck at me, then. He could not have won, but he could have tried. Instead he called down his precious One Power upon himself, so much that the earth split open and reared up Dragonmount to mark his tomb.

"ə θaʊzən jɪɹz leɪɾɝ aɪ sɛn ðə tʃɹɑləks ɹeɪvinɪŋ saʊθ, ən fəɹ θɹi sɛntʃɝiz ðeɪ sævɪdʒ ðə wɝld. ðoʊz blaɪn fulz ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn sɛɾ aɪ wɑz biɾən ɪn ði ɛnd, bʌt ðə sɛkən kʌvənənt, ðə kʌvənən ə ðə tɛn neɪʃənz, wɑz ʃæɾɝd bɪɑn ɹimeɪkɪŋ, ən u wɑz lɛf tə əpoʊz mi ðɛn? aɪ wɪspɝɾ ɪn ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz ɪɹ, ən ðə lɛŋθ ən bɹɛdθ ə ðə læn ɛɛs sədaɪ daɪd. aɪ wɪspɝɾ əɡɛn, ən ðə haɪ kɪŋ sɛn ɪz ɑɹmiz əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, əkɹɔs ðə wɝl si, ən sil tu dumz. ðə dum ə hɪz dʒɹim ʌv wʌn læn ən wʌn pipəl, ən ə dum jɛt tə kʌm. əɾ ɪz dɛθbɛɾ aɪ wɑz ðəɹ wən ɪz kaʊnsəlɝz toʊld ɪm oʊnli ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd seɪv ɪz laɪf. aɪ spoʊk, ən i ɔɹɾɝd ɪz kaʊnsəlɝz tə ðə steɪk. aɪ spoʊk, ən ðə haɪ kɪŋz læst wɝdz wɝ tə kɹaɪ ðət tɑɹ vəlɑn mʌs bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd.

"A thousand years later I sent the Trollocs ravening south, and for three centuries they savaged the world. Those blind fools in Tar Valon said I was beaten in the end, but the Second Covenant, the Covenant of the Ten Nations, was shattered beyond remaking, and who was left to oppose me then? I whispered in Artur Hawkwing's ear, and the length and breadth of the land Aes Sedai died. I whispered again, and the High King sent his armies across the Aryth Ocean, across the World Sea, and sealed two dooms. The doom of his dream of one land and one people, and a doom yet to come. At his deathbed I was there when his councilors told him only Aes Sedai could save his life. I spoke, and he ordered his councilors to the stake. I spoke, and the High King's last words were to cry that Tar Valon must be destroyed.

"wɛn mɛn sətʃ əz ðiz kəd nɑt stæn əɡɛns mi, wʌt tʃæns dʒju hæv, ə toʊd kɹaʊtʃɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ə fɔɹəs pʌɾəl. jəl sɝv mi, əɹ jəl dæns ɑn ɛɛs sədaɪ stʃɹɪŋz əntɪl jə daɪ. ən ðən jəl bi maɪn. ðə dɛd bɪlɔŋ tə mi!"

"When men such as these could not stand against me, what chance do you have, a toad crouching beside a forest puddle. You will serve me, or you will dance on Aes Sedai strings until you die. And then you will be mine. The dead belong to me!"

"noʊ," ɹænd mʌɾɝd, "ðɪs ɪz ə dʒɹim. ɪts ə dʒɹim!"

"No," Rand muttered, "this is a dream. It is a dream!"

"du jə θɪŋk jə ɑɹ seɪf fɹəm mi ɪn jəɹ dʒɹimz? lʊk!" bælzəmən pɔɪntəd kəmændɪŋli, ən ɹændz hɛd tɝn tə fɑloʊ, ɔlðoʊ hi dɪd nɑt tɝn ɪt; hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə tɝn.

"Do you think you are safe from me in your dreams? Look!" Ba'alzamon pointed commandingly, and Rand's head turned to follow, although he did not turn it; he did not want to turn.

ðə ɡɑblət wɑz ɡɔn fɹəm ðə teɪbəl. wɛɹ ɪt hæd bɪn, kɹaʊtʃt ə lɑɹdʒ ɹæt, blɪŋkɪŋ ət ðə laɪt, snɪfɪŋ ði ɛɹ wɛɹəli. bælzəmən kɹʊkəɾ ɪz fɪŋɡɝ, ən wɪð ə skwik ðə ɹæɾ ɑɹtʃt ɪts bæk, fɹpɔz lɪftɪŋ ɪndə ði ɛɹ waɪl ɪt bælənst ɔkwɝdli ɑn ɪts haɪn fit. ðə fɪŋɡɝ kɝv mɔɹ, ən ðə ɹæt tɑpəld oʊvɝ, skɹæbəlɪŋ fɹæntəkəli, pɔɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ, skwilɪŋ ʃɹɪli, ɪts bæk bɛndɪŋ, bɛndɪŋ, bɛndɪŋ. wɪð ə ʃɑɹp snæp laɪk ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ʌv ə twɪɡ, ðə ɹæt tʃɹɛmbəl vaɪələnli ən wɑz stɪl, laɪɪŋ bɛn ɔlmoʊs dʌbəl.

The goblet was gone from the table. Where it had been, crouched a large rat, blinking at the light, sniffing the air warily. Ba'alzamon crooked his finger, and with a squeak the rat arched its back, forepaws lifting into the air while it balanced awkwardly on its hind feet. The finger curved more, and the rat toppled over, scrabbling frantically, pawing at nothing, squealing shrilly, its back bending, bending, bending. With a sharp snap like the breaking of a twig, the rat trembled violently and was still, lying bent almost double.

ɹænd swɑloʊd. "ɛniθɪŋ kən hæpən ɪn ə dʒɹim," hi mʌmbəld. wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ i swʌŋ ɪz fɪs bæk əɡɛns ðə dɔɹ əɡɛn. hɪz hæn hɝt, bʌɾ i stɪl dɪd nɑt weɪk ʌp.

Rand swallowed. "Anything can happen in a dream," he mumbled. Without looking he swung his fist back against the door again. His hand hurt, but he still did not wake up.

"ðɛn ɡoʊ tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɡoʊ tə ðə waɪt taʊɝ ən tɛl ðɛm. tɛl ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ə ðɪs . . . dʒɹim." ðə mæn læft; ɹænd fɛl ðə hiɾ ə ðə fleɪmz ɑn ɪz feɪs. "ðæɾ ɪz wʌn weɪ tə ɪskeɪp ðɛm. ðəl nɑt juz ju, ðɛn. noʊ, nɑt wən ðeɪ noʊ ðəɾ aɪ noʊ. bʌt wɪl ðeɪ lɛt jə lɪv, tə spɹɛd ðə teɪl ʌv wʌt ðeɪ du? ɑɹ jə ə bɪɡ ɪnʌf ful tə bɪliv ðeɪ wɪl? ði æʃəz ə mɛni laɪk jə ɑɹ skæɾɝd ɑn ðə sloʊps ə dʒɹæɡoʊnmaʊnt."

"Then go to the Aes Sedai. Go to the White Tower and tell them. Tell the Amyrlin Seat of this . . . dream." The man laughed; Rand felt the heat of the flames on his face. "That is one way to escape them. They will not use you, then. No, not when they know that I know. But will they let you live, to spread the tale of what they do? Are you a big enough fool to believe they will? The ashes of many like you are scattered on the slopes of Dragonmount."

"ðɪs ɪz ə dʒɹim," ɹænd sɛd, pæntɪŋ. "ɪts ə dʒɹim, ən aɪm gɑnə weɪk ʌp."

"This is a dream," Rand said, panting. "It's a dream, and I am going to wake up."

"wɪl ju?" aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ hi sɔ ðə mænz fɪŋɡɝ muv tə pɔɪn ət hɪm. "wɪl ju, ɪndid?" ðə fɪŋɡɝ kɹʊkəd, ən ɹænd skɹimd əz i ɑɹtʃt bækwɝdz, ɛvɹi mʌsəl ɪn ɪz bɑɾi fɔɹsɪŋ ɪm fɝðɝ. "wɪl jə ɛvɝ weɪk əɡɛn?"

"Will you?" Out of the corner of his eye he saw the man's finger move to point at him. "Will you, indeed?" The finger crooked, and Rand screamed as he arched backwards, every muscle in his body forcing him further. "Will you ever wake again?"

kənvʌlsɪvli ɹænd dʒɝkt ʌp ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, hɪz hænz taɪɾənɪŋ ɑn klɔθ. ə blæŋkət. peɪl munlaɪt ʃoʊn θɹu ðə sɪŋɡəl wɪndoʊ. ðə ʃæɾoʊd ʃeɪps ə ði ʌðɝ tu bɛdz. ə snɔɹ fɹəm wʌn ə ðɛm, laɪk kænvəs ɹɪpɪŋ: tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn. ə fju koʊlz ɡlimd əmʌŋ ði æʃəz ɑn ðə hɑɹθ.

Convulsively Rand jerked up in the darkness, his hands tightening on cloth. A blanket. Pale moonlight shone through the single window. The shadowed shapes of the other two beds. A snore from one of them, like canvas ripping: Thom Merrilin. A few coals gleamed among the ashes on the hearth.

ɪt hæd bɪn ə dʒɹim, ðɛn, laɪk ðət naɪtmɛɹ ɪn ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn ðə deɪ ʌv bɛl taɪn, ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðəɾ i hæd hɝɾ ən dʌn ɔl dʒʌmbəld ɪn təɡɛðɝ wɪð oʊl teɪlz ən nɑnsɛns fɹəm noʊwɛɹ. hi pʊl ðə blæŋkəɾ ʌp ɝaʊn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt koʊl ðət meɪɾ ɪm ʃeɪk. hɪz hɛd hɝt, tu. pɝhæps mɔɪɹeɪn kəd də sʌmθɪŋ tə stɑp ðiz dʒɹimz. ʃi sɛd ʃi kəd hɛlp wɪð naɪtmɛɹz.

It had been a dream, then, like that nightmare in the Winespring Inn the day of Bel Tine, everything that he had heard and done all jumbled in together with old tales and nonsense from nowhere. He pulled the blanket up around his shoulders, but it was not cold that made him shake. His head hurt, too. Perhaps Moiraine could do something to stop these dreams. She said she could help with nightmares.

wɪð ə snɔɹɾ i leɪ bæk. wɝ ðə dʒɹimz ɹɪli bæɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə æsk ðə hɛlp ʌv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, kəɾ ɛniθɪŋ i dɪd naʊ ɡɛɾ ɪm ɪn ɛni dipɝ? hi hæd lɛf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, kʌm əweɪ wɪð ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌt ðəɹ hæd nɑt bɪn ɛni tʃɔɪs, ʌv kɔɹs. soʊ dɪɾ i hæv ɛni tʃɔɪs bʌt tə tʃɹʌs hɝ? ən ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɪt wɑz əz bæɾ əz ðə dʒɹimz, θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt. hi hʌɾəld ʌndɝ ɪz blæŋkət, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ðə kɑmnəs ə ðə vɔɪd ðə weɪ tæm hæd tɔt hɪm, bʌt slip wɑz ə lɔŋ taɪm ɹɪtɝnɪŋ.

With a snort he lay back. Were the dreams really bad enough for him to ask the help of an Aes Sedai? On the other hand, could anything he did now get him in any deeper? He had left the Two Rivers, come away with an Aes Sedai. But there had not been any choice, of course. So did he have any choice but to trust her? An Aes Sedai? It was as bad as the dreams, thinking about it. He huddled under his blanket, trying to find the calmness of the void the way Tam had taught him, but sleep was a long time returning.


tʃæptɝ fɪftin


CHAPTER 15

stʃɹeɪnʒɝz ən fɹɛnz


Strangers and Friends

sʌnlaɪt stʃɹimɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪz nɛɹoʊ bɛd faɪnəli woʊk ɹænd aʊɾ ʌv ə dip bʌt ɹɛsləs slip. hi pʊld ə pɪloʊ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt ɹɪli ʃʌɾ aʊt ðə laɪt, ən i dɪd nɑt ɹɪli wɑnə ɡoʊ bæk tə slip. ðəɹ hæd bɪn mɔɹ dʒɹimz æftɝ ðə fɝst. hi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛni bʌt ðə fɝst, bʌɾ i nu hi wɑntəd noʊ mɔɹ.

Sunlight streaming across his narrow bed finally woke Rand out of a deep but restless sleep. He pulled a pillow over his head, but it did not really shut out the light, and he did not really want to go back to sleep. There had been more dreams after the first. He could not remember any but the first, but he knew he wanted no more.

wɪð ə saɪ hi tɔs ðə pɪloʊ əsaɪɾ ən sæɾ ʌp, wɪnsɪŋ əz i stʃɹɛtʃt. ɔl ði eɪks i θɔt hæd soʊkt aʊɾ ɪn ðə bæθ wɝ bæk. ən ɪz hɛd stɪl hɝt, tu. ɪt dɪd nɑt sɝpɹaɪz hɪm. ə dʒɹim laɪk ðət wɑz ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ɛnibəɾi ə hɛdeɪk. ði ʌðɝz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi feɪɾəd, bʌt nɑt ðət wʌn.

With a sigh he tossed the pillow aside and sat up, wincing as he stretched. All the aches he thought had soaked out in the bath were back. And his head still hurt, too. It did not surprise him. A dream like that was enough to give anybody a headache. The others had already faded, but not that one.

ði ʌðɝ bɛdz wɝ ɛmpti. laɪt pɔɹɾ ɪn θɹu ðə wɪndoʊ əɾ ə stip æŋɡəl; ðə sʌn stʊd wɛl əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən. baɪ ðɪs aʊɝ bæk ɑn ðə fɑɹm i wəɾ əv ɔlɹɛɾi fɪkst sʌmθɪŋ tə iɾ ən bɪn wɛl ɪndə hɪz tʃɔɹz. hi skɹæmbəld aʊɾ ə bɛd, mʌɾɝɪŋ æŋɡɹəli tə hɪmsɛlf. ə sɪɾi tə si, ən ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ivən weɪk hɪm. ət list sʌmwʌn hæd sin ðət ðəɹ wɑz wɔɾɝ ɪn ðə pɪtʃɝ, ən stɪl wɔɹm, tu.

The other beds were empty. Light poured in through the window at a steep angle; the sun stood well above the horizon. By this hour back on the farm he would have already fixed something to eat and been well into his chores. He scrambled out of bed, muttering angrily to himself. A city to see, and they did not even wake him. At least someone had seen that there was water in the pitcher, and still warm, too.

hi wɑʃt ən dʒɹɛs kwɪkli, hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ ə moʊmən oʊvɝ tæmz sɔɹd. læn ən tɑm hæd lɛf ðɛɹ sæɾəlbæɡz ən blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊlz bɪhaɪn ɪn ðə ɹum, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝz sɔɹd wɑz noʊwɛɹ tə bi sin. læn hæd wɔɹn ɪz sɔɹɾ ɪn ɛmənz fild ivən bɪfɔɹ ðəɹ wɑz ɛni hɪn ə tʃɹʌbəl. hi θɔɾ i wəd teɪk ði oʊldɝ mænz lɛd. tɛlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪt wɑz nɑt kəz i hæɾ ɔfən deɪdʒɹimd əbaʊt wɔkɪŋ ðə stʃɹits ʌv ə ɹil sɪɾi wɛɹɪŋ ə sɔɹd, hi bɛltəɾ ɪɾ ɑn ən tɔst ɪz kloʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ laɪk ə sæk.

He washed and dressed quickly, hesitating a moment over Tam's sword. Lan and Thom had left their saddlebags and blanketrolls behind in the room, of course, but the Warder's sword was nowhere to be seen. Lan had worn his sword in Emond's Field even before there was any hint of trouble. He thought he would take the older man's lead. Telling himself it was not because he had often daydreamed about walking the streets of a real city wearing a sword, he belted it on and tossed his cloak over his shoulder like a sack.

teɪkɪŋ ðə stɛɹz tu əɾ ə taɪm, hi hɝid daʊn tə ðə kɪtʃən. ðət wɑz ʃʊɹli ðə kwɪkɪs pleɪs tə ɡɛɾ ə baɪt, ən ɑn ɪz oʊnli deɪ ɪn bɛɹlən i dɪd nɑt wɑnə weɪst ɛni mɔɹ taɪm ðən i ɔlɹɛɾi hæd. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, bʌt ðeɪ cʊɾə weɪk mi.

Taking the stairs two at a time, he hurried down to the kitchen. That was surely the quickest place to get a bite, and on his only day in Baerlon he did not want to waste any more time than he already had. Blood and ashes, but they could have waked me.

mæstɝ fɪtʃ wɑz ɪn ðə kɪtʃən, kənfɹʌntɪŋ ə plʌmp wʊmən huz ɑɹmz wɝ kʌvɝɾ ɪn flaʊɝ tə hɝ ɛlboʊz, ɑbviəsli ðə kʊk. ɹæðɝ, ʃi wɑz kənfɹʌntɪŋ hɪm, ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ fɪŋɡɝ ʌndɝ ɪz noʊz. sɝvɪŋ meɪdz ən skʌljənz, pɑtbɔɪz ən spɪtbɔɪz, hɝiɾ əbaʊt ðɛɹ tæsks, ɪlæbɹətli ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm.

Master Fitch was in the kitchen, confronting a plump woman whose arms were covered in flour to her elbows, obviously the cook. Rather, she was confronting him, shaking her finger under his nose. Serving maids and scullions, potboys and spitboys, hurried about their tasks, elaborately ignoring what was going on in front of them.

". . . maɪ sɹi ɪz ə ɡʊd kæt," ðə kʊk wɑz seɪɪŋ ʃɑɹpli, "æn aɪ woʊn hɪɹ ə wɝɾ ʌðɝwaɪz, dʒju hɪɹ? kəmpleɪnɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪm duɪŋ ɪz dʒɑb tu wɛl, ðæts wʌt jəɹ duɪŋ, ɪf jə æsk mi."

". . . my Cirri is a good cat," the cook was saying sharply, "and I won't hear a word otherwise, do you hear? Complaining about him doing his job too well, that's what you're doing, if you ask me."

"aɪ hæv hæd kəmpleɪns," mæstɝ fɪtʃ mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ɪn. "kəmpleɪns, mɪstʃɹəs. hæf ðə ɡɛsts - "

"I have had complaints," Master Fitch managed to get in. "Complaints, mistress. Half the guests - "

"aɪ woʊn hɪɹ ʌv ɪt. aɪ dʒʌst woʊn hɪɹ ʌv ɪt. ɪf ðeɪ wɑnə kəmpleɪn əbaʊt maɪ kæt, lɛɾ əm də ðə kʊkɪŋ. maɪ pʊɹ oʊl kæt, huz dʒʌs duɪŋ ɪz dʒɑb, ən mi, wɪl ɡoʊ sʌmwɛɹ wɛɹ wɝ əpɹiʃieɪɾɪd, si ɪf wi doʊnt." ʃi əntaɪɾ əɹ eɪpɹən ən stɑɹɾəd tə lɪft ɪɾ oʊvɝ əɹ hɛd.

"I won't hear of it. I just won't hear of it. If they want to complain about my cat, let them do the cooking. My poor old cat, who's just doing his job, and me, we'll go somewhere where we're appreciated, see if we don't." She untied her apron and started to lift it over her head.

"noʊ!" mæstɝ fɪtʃ jɛlpt, ən lɛp tə stɑp hɝ. ðeɪ dænst ɪn ə sɝkəl wɪð ðə kʊk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk əɹ eɪpɹən ɔf ən ði ɪnkipɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊɾ ɪt bæk ɑn hɝ. "noʊ, sɛɹə," hi pæntɪd. "ðɛɹz noʊ nid fəɹ ðɪs. noʊ nid, aɪ seɪ! wʌt wəɾ aɪ də wɪθaʊt ju? sɹiz ə faɪn kæt. ən ɛksələn kæt. hiz ðə bɛs kæɾ ɪn bɛɹlən. ɪf ɛniwʌn ɛls kəmpleɪnz, əl tɛl əm tə bi θæŋkfəl ðə kæɾ ɪz duɪŋ ɪz dʒɑb. jɛs, θæŋkfəl. jə mʌsnt ɡoʊ. sɛɹə? sɛɹə!"

"No!" Master Fitch yelped, and leaped to stop her. They danced in a circle with the cook trying to take her apron off and the innkeeper trying to put it back on her. "No, Sara," he panted. "There's no need for this. No need, I say! What would I do without you? Cirri's a fine cat. An excellent cat. He's the best cat in Baerlon. If anyone else complains, I'll tell them to be thankful the cat is doing his job. Yes, thankful. You mustn't go. Sara? Sara!"

ðə kʊk stɑp ðɛɹ sɝkəlɪŋ ən mænədʒ tə snætʃ əɹ eɪpɹən fɹi ʌv hɪm. "ɔl ɹaɪt, ðɛn. ɔl ɹaɪt." klʌtʃɪŋ ði eɪpɹən ɪn boʊθ hænz, ʃi stɪl dɪd nɑt ɹɛɾi ɪt. "bʌɾ ɪf jə ɪkspɛk mi tə hæv ɛniθɪŋ ɹɛɾi fəɹ mɪddeɪ, jud bɛst ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ ən lemi ɡɛt tə ɪt. ðɪs meɪ bi jəɹ ɪn, bʌɾ ɪts maɪ kɪtʃən. ənlɛs jə wɑnə də ðə kʊkɪŋ?" ʃi meɪɾ əz ɪf tə hæn ði eɪpɹən tə hɪm.

The cook stopped their circling and managed to snatch her apron free of him. "All right, then. All right." Clutching the apron in both hands, she still did not retie it. "But if you expect me to have anything ready for midday, you'd best get out of here and let me get to it. This may be your inn, but it's my kitchen. Unless you want to do the cooking?" She made as if to hand the apron to him.

mæstɝ fɪtʃ stɛp bæk wɪð ɪz hænz spɹɛd waɪd. hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ðən stɑpt, lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. ðə kɪtʃən hɛlp stɪl stuɾiəsli ɪɡnɔɹd ðə kʊk ən ði ɪnkipɝ, ən ɹænd bɪɡæn ən ɪntɛnsɪv sɝtʃ ə hɪz koʊt pɑkəts, ðoʊ ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə kɔɪn mɔɪɹeɪn hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɪn əm bʌɾ ə fju kɑpɝz ən ə hændfʊl ʌv ɑdz ən ɛnz. hɪz pɑkət naɪf ən ʃɑɹpənɪŋ stoʊn. tu spɛɹ bɑstʃɹɪŋz ən ə pis ə stʃɹɪŋ i hæd θɔt maɪt bi jusfəl.

Master Fitch stepped back with his hands spread wide. He opened his mouth, then stopped, looking around for the first time. The kitchen help still studiously ignored the cook and the innkeeper, and Rand began an intensive search of his coat pockets, though except for the coin Moiraine had given him there was nothing in them but a few coppers and a handful of odds and ends. His pocket knife and sharpening stone. Two spare bowstrings and a piece of string he had thought might be useful.

"aɪ æm ʃʊɹ, sɛɹə," mæstɝ fɪtʃ sɛd kɛɹfəli, "ðæɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɪl bi ʌp tə jəɹ juʒəwəl ɛksələns." wɪð ðəɾ i tʊk wʌn læst səspɪʃəs lʊk ət ðə kɪtʃən hɛlp, ðən lɛft wɪð əz mʌtʃ dɪɡnəɾi əz i kəd mænədʒ.

"I am sure, Sara," Master Fitch said carefully, "that everything will be up to your usual excellence." With that he took one last suspicious look at the kitchen help, then left with as much dignity as he could manage.

sɛɹə weɪɾəd əntɪl i wɑz ɡɔn bɪfɔɹ bɹɪskli taɪɪŋ əɹ eɪpɹən stʃɹɪŋz əɡɛn, ðən fæsən əɹ aɪ ɑn ɹænd. "aɪ səpoʊz jə wɑn sʌmθɪŋ tə it, ɛ? wɛl, kʌm ɑn ɪn." ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə kwɪk ɡɹɪn. "aɪ doʊn baɪt, aɪ doʊnt, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt jə meɪ hæv sin əz jə ʃʊdnt. sil, ɡɛt ðə læd səm bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz ən mɪlk. ðæts ɔl ðəɹ ɪz ɹaɪt naʊ. sɪt jɝsɛlf, læd. jəɹ fɹɛnz əv ɔl ɡɔn aʊt, ɪksɛpt wʌn læɾ aɪ ʌndɝstænd wɑzn filɪŋ wɛl, ən aɪ ɪkspɛk jəl bi wɑntɪŋ tə də ðə seɪm."

Sara waited until he was gone before briskly tying her apron strings again, then fastened her eye on Rand. "I suppose you want something to eat, eh? Well, come on in." She gave him a quick grin. "I don't bite, I don't, no matter what you may have seen as you shouldn't. Ciel, get the lad some bread and cheese and milk. That's all there is right now. Sit yourself, lad. Your friends have all gone out, except one lad I understand wasn't feeling well, and I expect you'll be wanting to do the same."

wʌn ə ðə sɝvɪŋ meɪdz bɹɔɾ ə tʃɹeɪ waɪl ɹænd tʊk ə stul ət ðə teɪbəl. hi bɪɡæn iɾɪŋ əz ðə kʊk wɛn bæk tə niɾɪŋ əɹ bɹɛd doʊ, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt fɪnɪʃt tɔkɪŋ.

One of the serving maids brought a tray while Rand took a stool at the table. He began eating as the cook went back to kneading her bread dough, but she was not finished talking.

"ju mʌsnt teɪk ɛni maɪn ʌv wʌt jə sɔ, naʊ. mæstɝ fɪtʃ ɪz ə ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf mæn, ðoʊ ðə bɛst ə jə ɑɹən ɛni bɑɹɡənz. ɪts ðə foʊk kəmpleɪnɪŋ əz əz ɪm ɑn ɛdʒ, ən wʌt də ðeɪv tə kəmpleɪn əbaʊt? wəd ðeɪ ɹæðɝ faɪn laɪv ɹæts ðən dɛd wʌnz? ðoʊ ɪɾ ɪzən laɪk sɹi tə liv ɪz hændiwɝk bɪhaɪnd. ən oʊvɝ ə dʌzən? sɹi wʊdn lɛt soʊ mɛni ɡɛɾ ɪndə ði ɪn, hi wʊdnt. ɪts ə klin pleɪs, tu, ən nɑt wʌn tə bi soʊ tʃɹʌbəld. ən ɔl wɪð bæks bɹoʊkən." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ət ðə stʃɹeɪnʒnəs ʌv ɪɾ ɔl.

"You mustn't take any mind of what you saw, now. Master Fitch is a good enough man, though the best of you aren't any bargains. It's the folk complaining as has him on edge, and what do they have to complain about? Would they rather find live rats than dead ones? Though it isn't like Cirri to leave his handiwork behind. And over a dozen? Cirri wouldn't let so many get into the inn, he wouldn't. It's a clean place, too, and not one to be so troubled. And all with backs broken." She shook her head at the strangeness of it all.

ðə bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz tɝn tə æʃəz ɪn ɹændz maʊð. "ðɛɹ bæks wɝ bɹoʊkən?"

The bread and cheese turned to ashes in Rand's mouth. "Their backs were broken?"

ðə kʊk weɪvd ə flaʊɝi hænd. "θɪŋk ɑn hæpiɝ θɪŋz, ðæts maɪ weɪ ʌv lʊkɪŋ. ðɛɹz ə ɡlimən, jə noʊ. ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum ɹaɪt ðɪs mɪnət. bʌt ðɛn, jə keɪm wɪð hɪm, dɪdn ju? jə ɑɹ wʌn ə ðoʊz əz keɪm wɪð mɪstʃɹəs æliz læst ivnɪŋ, ɑɹən ju? aɪ θɔt jə wɝ. aɪ woʊnt ɡɛt mʌtʃ tʃæns tə si ðɪs ɡlimən maɪsɛlf, aɪm θɪŋkɪŋ, nɑt wɪð ði ɪn əz fʊl əz ɪɾ ɪz, ən moʊst ə ðɛm ɹɪfɹæf daʊn fɹəm ðə maɪnz." ʃi ɡeɪv ðə doʊ ən ɪspɛʃli hɛvi θʌmp. "nɑt ðə sɔɹt wid lɛɾ ɪn moʊs taɪmz, oʊnli ðə hoʊl taʊn ɪz fɪld ʌp wɪð ðɛm. bɛɾɝ ðən səm ðeɪ kəd bi, ðoʊ, aɪ səpoʊz. waɪ, aɪ hævən sin ə ɡlimən sɪns bɪfɔɹ ðə wɪntɝ, ænd. . . ."

The cook waved a floury hand. "Think on happier things, that's my way of looking. There's a gleeman, you know. In the common room right this minute. But then, you came with him, didn't you? You are one of those as came with Mistress Alys last evening, aren't you? I thought you were. I won't get much chance to see this gleeman myself, I'm thinking, not with the inn as full as it is, and most of them riffraff down from the mines." She gave the dough an especially heavy thump. "Not the sort we'd let in most times, only the whole town is filled up with them. Better than some they could be, though, I suppose. Why, I haven't seen a gleeman since before the winter, and. . . ."

ɹænd eɪt məkænɪkli, nɑt teɪstɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ, nɑt lɪsnɪŋ tə wʌt ðə kʊk sɛd. dɛd ɹæts, wɪð ðɛɹ bæks bɹoʊkən. hi fɪnɪʃt ɪz bɹɛkfəs heɪstəli, stæmɝɾ ɪz θæŋks, ən hɝiɾ aʊt. hi hæd tə tɔk tə sʌmwʌn.

Rand ate mechanically, not tasting anything, not listening to what the cook said. Dead rats, with their backs broken. He finished his breakfast hastily, stammered his thanks, and hurried out. He had to talk to someone.

ðə kɑmən ɹum ə ðə stæɡ ən laɪən ʃɛɹd lɪɾəl ɪksɛpt ɪts pɝpəs wɪð ðə seɪm ɹum ət ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn. ɪt wɑz twaɪs əz waɪɾ ən θɹi taɪmz əz lɔŋ, ən kʌlɝfəl pɪktʃɝz ʌv ɔɹneɪt bɪldɪŋz wɪð ɡɑɹɾənz ə tɔl tʃɹiz ən bɹaɪt flaʊɝz wɝ peɪntəd haɪ ɑn ðə wɔlz. ɪnstɛɾ ʌv wʌn hjudʒ faɪɝpleɪs, ə hɑɹθ bleɪzd ɑn itʃ wɔl, ən skɔɹz ə teɪbəlz fɪl ðə flɔɹ, wɪð ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi tʃɛɹ, bɛntʃ, əɹ stul teɪkən.

The common room of the Stag and Lion shared little except its purpose with the same room at the Winespring Inn. It was twice as wide and three times as long, and colorful pictures of ornate buildings with gardens of tall trees and bright flowers were painted high on the walls. Instead of one huge fireplace, a hearth blazed on each wall, and scores of tables filled the floor, with almost every chair, bench, or stool taken.

ɛvɹi mæn əmʌŋ ðə kɹaʊɾ ə peɪtʃɹənz wɪð paɪps ɪn ðɛɹ tiθ ən mʌɡz ɪn ðɛɹ fɪsts lin fɔɹwɝd wɪð ɪz ətɛnʃən ɑn wʌn θɪŋ: tɑm, stændɪŋ ətɑp ə teɪbəl ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum, hɪz mɛni-kʌlɝd kloʊk tɔst oʊvɝ ə nɪɹbaɪ tʃɛɹ. ivən mæstɝ fɪtʃ hɛld ə sɪlvɝ tæŋkɝɾ ən ə pɑlɪʃɪŋ klɔθ ɪn moʊʃənləs hænz.

Every man among the crowd of patrons with pipes in their teeth and mugs in their fists leaned forward with his attention on one thing: Thom, standing atop a table in the middle of the room, his many-colored cloak tossed over a nearby chair. Even Master Fitch held a silver tankard and a polishing cloth in motionless hands.

". . . pɹænsɪŋ, sɪlvɝ hʊvz ən pɹaʊd, ɑɹtʃt nɛks," tɑm pɹoʊkleɪmd, waɪl sʌmhaʊ simɪŋ nɑɾ oʊnli tə bi ɹaɪɾɪŋ ə hɔɹs, bʌt tə bi wʌn ʌv ə lɔŋ pɹəsɛʃən ə ɹaɪɾɝz. "sɪlkən meɪnz flʌɾɝ wɪð tɔs hɛdz. ə θaʊzən stʃɹimɪŋ bænɝz wɪp ɹeɪnboʊz əɡɛnst ən ɛnləs skaɪ. ə hʌnʒɹəd bɹeɪzən-θɹoʊɾɪd tʃɹʌmpəts ʃɪvɝ ði ɛɹ, ən dʒɹʌmz ɹæɾəl laɪk θʌndɝ. weɪv ɑn weɪv, tʃɪɹz ɹoʊl fɹəm wɑtʃɝz ɪn ðɛɹ θaʊzənz, ɹoʊl əkɹɔs ðə ɹuftɑps ən taʊɝz ʌv ɪljən, kɹæʃ ən bɹeɪk ənhɝɾ ɝaʊn ðə θaʊzən ɪɹz ə ɹaɪɾɝz huz aɪz ən hɑɹts ʃaɪn wɪð ðɛɹ seɪkɹəd kwɛst. ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn ɹaɪdz fɔɹθ, ɹaɪdz tə sik ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ ðət wɪl sʌmən ðə hɪɹoʊz ə ði eɪdʒəz bæk fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪv tə bæɾəl fəɹ ðə laɪt. . . ."

". . . prancing, silver hooves and proud, arched necks," Thom proclaimed, while somehow seeming not only to be riding a horse, but to be one of a long procession of riders. "Silken manes flutter with tossed heads. A thousand streaming banners whip rainbows against an endless sky. A hundred brazen-throated trumpets shiver the air, and drums rattle like thunder. Wave on wave, cheers roll from watchers in their thousands, roll across the rooftops and towers of Illian, crash and break unheard around the thousand ears of riders whose eyes and hearts shine with their sacred quest. The Great Hunt of the Horn rides forth, rides to seek the Horn of Valere that will summon the heroes of the Ages back from the grave to battle for the Light. . . ."

ɪt wɑz wʌt ðə ɡlimən hæd kɔl pleɪn tʃænt, ðoʊz naɪts bɪsaɪd ðə faɪɝ ɑn ðə ɹaɪd nɔɹθ. stɔɹiz, hi sɛd, wɝ toʊld ɪn θɹi vɔɪsəz, haɪ tʃænt, pleɪn tʃænt, ən kɑmən, wɪtʃ mɛn sɪmpli tɛlɪŋ ɪt ðə weɪ jə maɪt tɛl jəɹ neɪbɝ əbaʊt jəɹ kɹɑp. tɑm toʊl stɔɹiz ɪn kɑmən, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə haɪɾ ɪz kəntɛmp fəɹ ðə vɔɪs.

It was what the gleeman had called Plain Chant, those nights beside the fire on the ride north. Stories, he said, were told in three voices, High Chant, Plain Chant, and Common, which meant simply telling it the way you might tell your neighbor about your crop. Thom told stories in Common, but he did not bother to hide his contempt for the voice.

ɹænd kloʊz ðə dɔɹ wɪθaʊt ɡoʊɪŋ ɪn ən slʌmpt əɡɛns ðə wɔl. hi wəd ɡɛt noʊ ædvaɪs fɹəm tɑm. mɔɪɹeɪn - wʌt wəd ʃi də ɪf ʃi nu?

Rand closed the door without going in and slumped against the wall. He would get no advice from Thom. Moiraine - what would she do if she knew?

hi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə pipəl stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm əz ðeɪ pæst, ən ɹilaɪzd i wɑz mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. smuðɪŋ ɪz koʊt, hi stʃɹeɪɾənd. hi hæd tə tɔk tə sʌmbɑɾi. ðə kʊk hæd sɛd wʌn ə ði ʌðɝz hæd nɑt ɡɔn aʊt. ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt nɑt tə ɹʌn.

He became aware of people staring at him as they passed, and realized he was muttering under his breath. Smoothing his coat, he straightened. He had to talk to somebody. The cook had said one of the others had not gone out. It was an effort not to run.

wən i ɹæpt ɑn ðə dɔɹ ə ðə ɹum wɛɹ ði ʌðɝ bɔɪz hæd slɛpt ən poʊkt ɪz hɛɾ ɪn, oʊnli pɛɹɪn wɑz ðɛɹ, laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪz bɛɾ ən stɪl nɑt dʒɹɛst. hi twɪstəɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɑn ðə pɪloʊ tə lʊk ət ɹænd, ðən kloʊzd ɪz aɪz əɡɛn. mæts baʊ ən kwɪvɝ wɝ pɹɑpt ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ.

When he rapped on the door of the room where the other boys had slept and poked his head in, only Perrin was there, lying on his bed and still not dressed. He twisted his head on the pillow to look at Rand, then closed his eyes again. Mat's bow and quiver were propped in the corner.

"aɪ hɝd jə wɝn filɪŋ wɛl," ɹænd sɛd. hi keɪm ɪn ən sæɾ ɑn ðə nɛks bɛd. "aɪ dʒʌst wɑntəd tə tɔk. aɪ. . . ." hi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ tə bɹɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp, hi ɹilaɪzd. "ɪf jəɹ sɪk," hi sɛd, hæf stændɪŋ, "meɪbi jə ɔt tə slip. aɪ kən ɡoʊ."

"I heard you weren't feeling well," Rand said. He came in and sat on the next bed. "I just wanted to talk. I. . . ." He did not know how to bring it up, he realized. "If you're sick," he said, half standing, "maybe you ought to sleep. I can go."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf əl ɛvɝ slip əɡɛn." pɛɹɪn saɪd. "aɪ hæɾ ə bæd dʒɹim, ɪf jə mʌs noʊ, ən kʊdnt ɡɛt bæk tə slip. mæt wɪl bi kwɪk ɪnʌf tə tɛl ju. hi læf ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ, wən aɪ toʊld əm waɪ aɪ wɑz tu taɪɝd tə ɡoʊ aʊt wɪð hɪm, bʌɾ i dʒɹimd, tu. aɪ lɪsən tə hɪm fəɹ moʊst ə ðə naɪt, tɔsɪŋ ən mʌɾɝɪŋ, ən jə kæn tɛl mi hi ɡɑɾ ə ɡʊd naɪts slip." hi θɹu ə θɪk ɑɹm əkɹɔs ɪz aɪz. "laɪt, bʌɾ aɪm taɪɝd. meɪbi ɪf aɪ dʒʌst steɪ hɪɹ fəɹ ən aʊɝ əɹ tu, əl fil laɪk ɡɛɾɪŋ ʌp. mæt wɪl nɛvɝ lemi hɪɹ ði ɛn ʌv ɪɾ ɪf aɪ mɪs siɪŋ bɛɹlən kəz ʌv ə dʒɹim."

"I don't know if I'll ever sleep again." Perrin sighed. "I had a bad dream, if you must know, and couldn't get back to sleep. Mat will be quick enough to tell you. He laughed this morning, when I told them why I was too tired to go out with him, but he dreamed, too. I listened to him for most of the night, tossing and muttering, and you can't tell me he got a good night's sleep." He threw a thick arm across his eyes. "Light, but I'm tired. Maybe if I just stay here for an hour or two, I'll feel like getting up. Mat will never let me hear the end of it if I miss seeing Baerlon because of a dream."

ɹænd sloʊli loʊɝd hɪmsɛlf tə ðə bɛɾ əɡɛn. hi lɪkt ɪz lɪps, ðən sɛd kwɪkli, "dɪɾ i kɪl ə ɹæt?"

Rand slowly lowered himself to the bed again. He licked his lips, then said quickly, "Did he kill a rat?"

pɛɹɪn loʊɝɾ ɪz ɑɹm ən stɛɹɾ ət hɪm. "ju, tu?" hi sɛd faɪnəli. wən ɹænd nɑɾəd, hi sɛd, "aɪ wɪʃ aɪ wɑz bæk hoʊm. hi toʊl mi . . . hi sɛd. . . . wʌɾ ɑɹ wi ɡoʊɪŋ tə du? hæv jə toʊl mɔɪɹeɪn?"

Perrin lowered his arm and stared at him. "You, too?" he said finally. When Rand nodded, he said, "I wish I was back home. He told me . . . he said. . . . What are we going to do? Have you told Moiraine?"

"noʊ. nɑt jɛt. meɪbi aɪ woʊnt. aɪ doʊnt noʊ. wʌɾ əbaʊt ju?"

"No. Not yet. Maybe I won't. I don't know. What about you?"

"hi sɛd. . . . blʌɾ ən æʃəz, ɹænd, aɪ doʊnt noʊ." pɛɹɪn ɹeɪzd ʌp ɑn ɪz ɛlboʊ əbɹʌpli. "du jə θɪŋk mæt hæd ðə seɪm dʒɹim? hi læft, bʌɾ ɪt saʊndəd fɔɹst, ən i lʊk fʌni wən aɪ sɛɾ aɪ kʊdn slip kəz ʌv ə dʒɹim."

"He said. . . . Blood and ashes, Rand, I don't know." Perrin raised up on his elbow abruptly. "Do you think Mat had the same dream? He laughed, but it sounded forced, and he looked funny when I said I couldn't sleep because of a dream."

"meɪbi hi dɪd," ɹænd sɛd. ɡɪltəli, hi fɛlt ɹɪlivd i wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn. "aɪ wɑz gɑnə æsk tɑm fəɹ ædvaɪs. hiz sin ə lɑɾ ə ðə wɝld. jə . . . jə doʊn θɪŋk wi ʃəd tɛl mɔɪɹeɪn, də ju?"

"Maybe he did," Rand said. Guiltily, he felt relieved he was not the only one. "I was going to ask Thom for advice. He's seen a lot of the world. You . . . you don't think we should tell Moiraine, do you?"

pɛɹɪn fɛl bæk ɑn ɪz pɪloʊ. "juv hɝd ðə stɔɹiz əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. dʒju θɪŋk wi kən tʃɹʌs tɑm? ɪf wi kən tʃɹʌst ɛnibəɾi. ɹænd, ɪf wi ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðɪs əlaɪv, ɪf wi ɛvɝ ɡɛt bæk hoʊm, ən jə hɪɹ mi seɪ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt livɪŋ ɛmənz fild, ivən tə ɡoʊ əz fɑɹ əz wɑtʃ hɪl, jə kɪk mi. ɔl ɹaɪt?"

Perrin fell back on his pillow. "You've heard the stories about Aes Sedai. Do you think we can trust Thom? If we can trust anybody. Rand, if we get out of this alive, if we ever get back home, and you hear me say anything about leaving Emond's Field, even to go as far as Watch Hill, you kick me. All right?"

"ðæts noʊ weɪ tə tɔk," ɹænd sɛd. hi pʊɾ ɑn ə smaɪl, əz tʃɪɹfəl əz i kəd meɪk ɪt. "ʌv kɔɹs wɪl ɡɛt hoʊm. kʌm ɑn, ɡɛɾ ʌp. wɝ ɪn ə sɪɾi, ən wɪv ə hoʊl deɪ tə si ɪt. wɛɹ ɑɹ jəɹ kloʊðz?"

"That's no way to talk," Rand said. He put on a smile, as cheerful as he could make it. "Of course we'll get home. Come on, get up. We're in a city, and we have a whole day to see it. Where are your clothes?"

"ju ɡoʊ. aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə laɪ hɪɹ əwaɪl." pɛɹɪn pʊɾ ɪz ɑɹm bæk əkɹɔs ɪz aɪz. "ju ɡoʊ əhɛd. əl kætʃ jə ʌp ɪn ən aʊɝ əɹ tu."

"You go. I just want to lie here awhile." Perrin put his arm back across his eyes. "You go ahead. I'll catch you up in an hour or two."

"ɪts jəɹ lɔs," ɹænd sɛɾ əz i ɡɑɾ ʌp. "θɪŋk ʌv wʌt jə maɪt mɪs." hi stɑpt ət ðə dɔɹ. "bɛɹlən. haʊ mɛni taɪmz əv wi tɔkt əbaʊt siɪŋ bɛɹlən wʌn deɪ?" pɛɹɪn leɪ ðəɹ wɪð ɪz aɪz kʌvɝɾ ən dɪd nɑt seɪ ə wɝd. æftɝ ə mɪnət ɹænd stɛpt aʊɾ ən kloʊz ðə dɔɹ bɪhaɪn hɪm.

"It's your loss," Rand said as he got up. "Think of what you might miss." He stopped at the door. "Baerlon. How many times have we talked about seeing Baerlon one day?" Perrin lay there with his eyes covered and did not say a word. After a minute Rand stepped out and closed the door behind him.

ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ hi lin əɡɛns ðə wɔl, hɪz smaɪl feɪɾɪŋ. hɪz hɛd stɪl hɝt; ɪt wɑz wɝs, nɑt bɛɾɝ. hi kəd nɑt wɝk ʌp mʌtʃ ɪnθuziæzəm fəɹ bɛɹlən, iðɝ, nɑt naʊ. hi kəd nɑt sʌmən ɪnθuziæzəm əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ.

In the hallway he leaned against the wall, his smile fading. His head still hurt; it was worse, not better. He could not work up much enthusiasm for Baerlon, either, not now. He could not summon enthusiasm about anything.

ə tʃeɪmbɝmeɪd keɪm baɪ, hɝ ɑɹmz fʊl ə ʃits, ən ɡeɪv ɪm ə kənsɝn lʊk. bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd spik i muvd ɔf daʊn ðə hɔl, ʃɹʌɡɪŋ ɪndə hɪz kloʊk. tɑm wəd nɑt bi fɪnɪʃt ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum fəɹ aʊɝz jɛt. hi maɪɾ əz wɛl si wʌɾ i kʊd. pɝhæps i kəd faɪn mæt, ən si ɪf bælzəmən hæd bɪn ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz, tu. hi wɛn daʊnstɛɹz mɔɹ sloʊli ðɪs taɪm, ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz tɛmpəl.

A chambermaid came by, her arms full of sheets, and gave him a concerned look. Before she could speak he moved off down the hall, shrugging into his cloak. Thom would not be finished in the common room for hours yet. He might as well see what he could. Perhaps he could find Mat, and see if Ba'alzamon had been in his dreams, too. He went downstairs more slowly this time, rubbing his temple.

ðə stɛɹz ɛndəd nɪɹ ðə kɪtʃən, soʊ hi tʊk ðət weɪ aʊt, nɑɾɪŋ tə sɛɹə bʌt hɝiɪŋ ɑn wən ʃi simd əbaʊt tə teɪk ʌp wɛɹ ʃi hæd lɛft ɔf. ðə steɪbliɑɹd wɑz ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ mʌtʃ, stændɪŋ ɪn ðə steɪbəl dɔɹ, ən wʌn ə ði ʌðɝ ɑslɝz kæɹiɪŋ ə sæk ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ɪndə ðə steɪbəl. ɹænd nɑɾəd tə mʌtʃ, tu, bʌt ðə steɪbəlmən ɡeɪv ɪm ə tʃɹʌkjələn lʊk ən wɛn ɪnsaɪd. hi hoʊp ðə ɹɛst ə ðə sɪɾi wɑz mɔɹ laɪk sɛɹə ən lɛs laɪk mʌtʃ. ɹɛɾi tə si wʌɾ ə sɪɾi wɑz laɪk, hi pɪkt ʌp ɪz stɛp.

The stairs ended near the kitchen, so he took that way out, nodding to Sara but hurrying on when she seemed about to take up where she had left off. The stableyard was empty except for Mutch, standing in the stable door, and one of the other ostlers carrying a sack on his shoulder into the stable. Rand nodded to Mutch, too, but the stableman gave him a truculent look and went inside. He hoped the rest of the city was more like Sara and less like Mutch. Ready to see what a city was like, he picked up his step.

ət ði oʊpən steɪbliɑɹd ɡeɪts, hi stɑpt ən stɛɹd. pipəl pæk ðə stʃɹit laɪk ʃip ɪn ə pɛn, pipəl swɑð tə ði aɪz ɪn kloʊks ən koʊts, hæts pʊl daʊn əɡɛns ðə koʊld, wivɪŋ ɪn ən aʊɾ əɾ ə kwɪk stɛp əz ðoʊ ðə wɪnd wɪslɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə ɹuftɑps blu ðɛm əlɔŋ, ɛlboʊɪŋ pæst wʌn ənʌðɝ wɪð bɛɹli ə wɝɾ əɹ ə ɡlæns. ɔl stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, hi θɔt. nʌn ə ðɛm noʊ itʃ ʌðɝ.

At the open stableyard gates, he stopped and stared. People packed the street like sheep in a pen, people swathed to the eyes in cloaks and coats, hats pulled down against the cold, weaving in and out at a quick step as though the wind whistling over the rooftops blew them along, elbowing past one another with barely a word or a glance. All strangers, he thought. None of them know each other.

ðə smɛlz wɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ, tu, ʃɑɹp ən saʊɝ ən swiɾ ɔl mɪkst ɪn ə hɑdʒpɑdʒ ðət hæɾ ɪm ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz noʊz. ivən ət ðə haɪɾ ə fɛstəvəl i hæd nɛvɝ sin soʊ mɛni pipəl soʊ dʒæm təɡɛðɝ. nɑɾ ivən hæf soʊ mɛni. ən ðɪs wɑz oʊnli wʌn stʃɹit. mæstɝ fɪtʃ ən ðə kʊk sɛd ðə hoʊl sɪɾi wɑz fʊl. ðə hoʊl sɪɾi . . . laɪk ðɪs?

The smells were strange, too, sharp and sour and sweet all mixed in a hodgepodge that had him rubbing his nose. Even at the height of Festival he had never seen so many people so jammed together. Not even half so many. And this was only one street. Master Fitch and the cook said the whole city was full. The whole city . . . like this?

hi bæk sloʊli əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɡeɪt, əweɪ fɹəm ðə stʃɹit fʊl ə pipəl. ɪt ɹɪli wɑz nɑt ɹaɪt tə ɡoʊ ɔf ən liv pɛɹɪn sɪk ɪn bɛd. ən wʌɾ ɪf tɑm fɪnɪʃt ɪz stɔɹitɛlɪŋ waɪl ɹænd wɑz ɔf ɪn ðə sɪɾi? ðə ɡlimən maɪt ɡoʊ aʊt hɪmsɛlf, ən ɹænd niɾəd tə tɔk tə sʌmwʌn. mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ tə weɪɾ ə bɪt. hi bɹiðd ə saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif əz i tɝn ɪz bæk ɑn ðə swɔɹmɪŋ stʃɹit.

He backed slowly away from the gate, away from the street full of people. It really was not right to go off and leave Perrin sick in bed. And what if Thom finished his storytelling while Rand was off in the city? The gleeman might go out himself, and Rand needed to talk to someone. Much better to wait a bit. He breathed a sigh of relief as he turned his back on the swarming street.

ɡoʊɪŋ bæk ɪnsaɪd ði ɪn dɪd nɑɾ əpil tə hɪm, ðoʊ, nɑt wɪð ɪz hɛdeɪk. hi sæɾ ɑn ən ʌpɛndəd bæɹəl əɡɛns ðə bæk ə ði ɪn ən hoʊp ðə koʊld ɛɹ maɪt hɛlp ɪz hɛd.

Going back inside the inn did not appeal to him, though, not with his headache. He sat on an upended barrel against the back of the inn and hoped the cold air might help his head.

mʌtʃ keɪm tə ðə steɪbəl dɔɹ fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm tə stɛɹ ət hɪm, ən ivən əkɹɔs ðə steɪbliɑɹɾ i kəd meɪk aʊt ðə fɛloʊz dɪsəpɹuvɪŋ skaʊl. wɑz ɪt kʌntʃɹi pipəl ðə mæn dɪd nɑt laɪk? əɹ hæɾ i bɪn ɪmbɛɹəs baɪ mæstɝ fɪtʃ ɡɹiɾɪŋ əm æftɝ i hæd tʃɹaɪd tə tʃeɪs əm ɔf fəɹ kʌmɪŋ ɪn ðə bæk weɪ? meɪbi hiz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, hi θɔt, ɪkspɛktɪŋ tə tʃʌkəl ət ði aɪdiə, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə fʌni θɔt. hi ɹʌbd ɪz hæn əlɔŋ ðə hɪlt ə tæmz sɔɹd. ðəɹ wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ lɛf ðət wɑz fʌni əɾ ɔl.

Mutch came to the stable door from time to time to stare at him, and even across the stableyard he could make out the fellow's disapproving scowl. Was it country people the man did not like? Or had he been embarrassed by Master Fitch greeting them after he had tried to chase them off for coming in the back way? Maybe he's a Darkfriend, he thought, expecting to chuckle at the idea, but it was not a funny thought. He rubbed his hand along the hilt of Tam's sword. There was not much left that was funny at all.

"ə ʃɛpɝd wɪð ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk sɔɹd," sɛɾ ə loʊ, wʊmənz vɔɪs. "ðæts ɔlmoʊst ɪnʌf tə meɪk mi bɪliv ɛniθɪŋ. wʌt tʃɹʌbəl ɑɹ jə ɪn, daʊnkaʊntʃɹi bɔɪ?"

"A shepherd with a heron-mark sword," said a low, woman's voice. "That's almost enough to make me believe anything. What trouble are you in, downcountry boy?"

stɑɹɾəld, ɹænd dʒʌmp tə hɪz fit. ɪt wɑz ðə kɹɑp-hɛɹd jʌŋ wʊmən u hæd bɪn wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn wən i keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə bæθ tʃeɪmbɝ, stɪl dʒɹɛst ɪn ə bɔɪz koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz. ʃi wɑz ə lɪɾəl oʊldɝ ðən i wɑz, hi θɔt, wɪð dɑɹk aɪz ivən bɪɡɝ ðən ɛɡwinz, ən ɑdli ɪntɛnt.

Startled, Rand jumped to his feet. It was the crop-haired young woman who had been with Moiraine when he came out of the bath chamber, still dressed in a boy's coat and breeches. She was a little older than he was, he thought, with dark eyes even bigger than Egwene's, and oddly intent.

"ju ɑɹ ɹænd, ɑɹən ju?" ʃi wɛn ɑn. "maɪ neɪm ɪz mɪn."

"You are Rand, aren't you?" she went on. "My name is Min."

"aɪm nɑɾ ɪn tʃɹʌbəl," hi sɛd. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn hæd toʊl hɝ, bʌɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd lænz ædmənɪʃən nɑt tə ətʃɹækt ɛni noʊɾəs. "wʌt meɪks jə θɪŋk aɪm ɪn tʃɹʌbəl? ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɪz ə kwaɪət pleɪs, ən wɝ ɔl kwaɪət pipəl. noʊ pleɪs fəɹ tʃɹʌbəl, ənlɛs ɪts tə də wɪð kɹɑps, əɹ ʃip."

"I'm not in trouble," he said. He did not know what Moiraine had told her, but he remembered Lan's admonition not to attract any notice. "What makes you think I'm in trouble? The Two Rivers is a quiet place, and we're all quiet people. No place for trouble, unless it has to do with crops, or sheep."

"kwaɪət?" mɪn sɛd wɪð ə feɪn smaɪl. "aɪv hɝd mɛn tɔk əbaʊt jə tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk. aɪv hɝd ðə dʒoʊks əbaʊt wʊɾən-hɛdəd ʃifɝɾɝz, ən ðən ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛn u hæv æktʃəli  bɪn daʊnkaʊntʃɹi."

"Quiet?" Min said with a faint smile. "I've heard men talk about you Two Rivers folk. I've heard the jokes about wooden-headed sheepherders, and then there are men who have actually been downcountry."

"wʊɾən-hɛdəd?" ɹænd sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "wʌt dʒoʊks?"

"Wooden-headed?" Rand said, frowning. "What jokes?"

"ðə wʌnz u noʊ," ʃi wɛn ɑn əz ɪf i hæd nɑt spoʊkən, "seɪ jə wɔk ɝaʊn ɔl smaɪlz ən pəlaɪtnəs, dʒʌst əz mik ən sɑft əz bʌɾɝ. ɑn ðə sɝfəs, ɛniweɪ. ʌndɝniθ, ðeɪ seɪ, jəɹ ɔl əz tʌf əz oʊld oʊk ɹuts. pɹɑd tu hɑɹd, ðeɪ seɪ, ən jə dɪɡ ʌp stoʊn. bʌt ðə stoʊn ɪzən bɛɹid vɛɹi dip ɪn ju, əɹ ɪn jəɹ fɹɛnz. ɪts əz ɪf ə stɔɹm əz skaʊɝɾ əweɪ ɔlmoʊst ɔl ðə kʌvɝɪŋ. mɔɪɹeɪn dɪdn tɛl mi ɛvɹiθɪŋ, bʌɾ aɪ si wʌɾ aɪ si."

"The ones who know," she went on as if he had not spoken, "say you walk around all smiles and politeness, just as meek and soft as butter. On the surface, anyway. Underneath, they say, you're all as tough as old oak roots. Prod too hard, they say, and you dig up stone. But the stone isn't buried very deep in you, or in your friends. It's as if a storm has scoured away almost all the covering. Moiraine didn't tell me everything, but I see what I see."

oʊld oʊk ɹuts? stoʊn? ɪt hɑɹdli saʊndəd laɪk ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ ðə mɝtʃəns əɹ ðɛɹ pipəl wəd seɪ. ðət læs meɪɾ ɪm dʒʌmp, ðoʊ.

Old oak roots? Stone? It hardly sounded like the sort of thing the merchants or their people would say. That last made him jump, though.

hi lʊkt ɝaʊn kwɪkli; ðə steɪbliɑɹd wɑz ɛmpti, ən ðə nɪɹəst wɪndoʊz wɝ kloʊzd. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɛnibəɾi neɪmd - wʌt wɑz ɪɾ əɡɛn?"

He looked around quickly; the stableyard was empty, and the nearest windows were closed. "I don't know anybody named - what was it again?"

"mɪstʃɹəs æliz, ðɛn, ɪf jə pɹəfɝ," mɪn sɛd wɪð ən əmjuz lʊk ðət meɪɾ ɪz tʃiks kʌlɝ. "ðɛɹz noʊ wʌn kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ."

"Mistress Alys, then, if you prefer," Min said with an amused look that made his cheeks color. "There's no one close enough to hear."

"wʌt meɪks jə θɪŋk mɪstʃɹəs æliz əz ənʌðɝ neɪm?"

"What makes you think Mistress Alys has another name?"

"bɪkɔz ʃi toʊl mi," mɪn sɛd, soʊ peɪʃənli ðəɾ i blʌʃt əɡɛn. "nɑt ðət ʃi hæɾ ə tʃɔɪs, aɪ səpoʊz. aɪ sɔ ʃi wɑz . . . dɪfɹənt . . . ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. wən ʃi stɑp hɪɹ bɪfɔɹ, ɑn əɹ weɪ daʊnkaʊntʃɹi. ʃi nu əbaʊt mi. aɪv tɔk tə . . . ʌðɝz laɪk əɹ bɪfɔɹ."

"Because she told me," Min said, so patiently that he blushed again. "Not that she had a choice, I suppose. I saw she was . . . different . . . right away. When she stopped here before, on her way downcountry. She knew about me. I've talked to . . . others like her before."

" 'sɔ'?" ɹænd sɛd.

" 'Saw'?" Rand said.

"wɛl, aɪ doʊn səpoʊz jəl ɡoʊ ɹʌnɪŋ tə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. nɑt kənsɪɾɝɪŋ u jəɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ kəmpænjənz ɑɹ. ðə waɪtkloʊks wʊdn laɪk wʌɾ aɪ də ɛni mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ laɪk wʌt ʃi dʌz."

"Well, I don't suppose you'll go running to the Children. Not considering who your traveling companions are. The Whitecloaks wouldn't like what I do any more than they like what she does."

"aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd."

"I don't understand."

"ʃi sɛz aɪ si pisəz ə ðə pæɾɝn." mɪn ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl læf ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "saʊnz tu ɡɹænd, tə mi. aɪ dʒʌst si θɪŋz wən aɪ lʊk ət pipəl, ən səmtaɪmz aɪ noʊ wʌt ðeɪ min. aɪ lʊk əɾ ə mæn ən ə wʊmən huv nɛvɝ ivən tɔk tə wʌn ənʌðɝ, ən aɪ noʊ ðəl mɛɹi. ən ðeɪ du. ðət sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ. ʃi wɑntəd mi tə lʊk ət ju. ɔl ə jə təɡɛðɝ."

"She says I see pieces of the Pattern." Min gave a little laugh and shook her head. "Sounds too grand, to me. I just see things when I look at people, and sometimes I know what they mean. I look at a man and a woman who've never even talked to one another, and I know they'll marry. And they do. That sort of thing. She wanted me to look at you. All of you together."

ɹænd ʃɪvɝd. "ænd wʌd jə si?"

Rand shivered. "And what did you see?"

"wɛn jəɹ ɔl ɪn ə ɡɹup? spɑɹks swɝlɪŋ ɝaʊn ju, θaʊzənz ə ðɛm, ən ə bɪɡ ʃædoʊ, dɑɹkɝ ðən mɪdnaɪt. ɪts soʊ stʃɹɔŋ, aɪ ɔlmoʊst wʌndɝ waɪ ɛvɹibɑɾi kæn si ɪt. ðə spɑɹks ɑɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɪl ðə ʃædoʊ, ən ðə ʃædoʊ ɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə swɑloʊ ðə spɑɹks." ʃi ʃɹʌɡd. "ju ɑɹ ɔl taɪd təɡɛðɝ ɪn sʌmθɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs, bʌɾ aɪ kæn meɪk ɛni mɔɹ ʌv ɪt."

"When you're all in a group? Sparks swirling around you, thousands of them, and a big shadow, darker than midnight. It's so strong, I almost wonder why everybody can't see it. The sparks are trying to fill the shadow, and the shadow is trying to swallow the sparks." She shrugged. "You are all tied together in something dangerous, but I can't make any more of it."

"ɔl ʌv ʌs?" ɹænd mʌɾɝd. "ɛɡwin, tu? bʌt ðeɪ wɝn æftɝ - aɪ min - "

"All of us?" Rand muttered. "Egwene, too? But they weren't after - I mean - "

mɪn dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs ɪz slɪp. "ðə ɡɝl? ʃiz pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. ən ðə ɡlimən. ɔl ə ju. jəɹ ɪn lʌv wɪð hɝ." hi stɛɹɾ ət hɝ. "aɪ kən tɛl ðəɾ ivən wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ɛni ɪmədʒəz. ʃi lʌvz ju, tu, bʌt ʃiz nɑt fəɹ ju, əɹ jə fəɹ hɝ. nɑt ðə weɪ jə boʊθ wɑnt."

Min did not seem to notice his slip. "The girl? She's part of it. And the gleeman. All of you. You're in love with her." He stared at her. "I can tell that even without seeing any images. She loves you, too, but she's not for you, or you for her. Not the way you both want."

"wʌts ðət səpoʊz tə min?"

"What's that supposed to mean?"

"wɛn aɪ lʊk ət hɝ, aɪ si ðə seɪm əz wən aɪ lʊk ət . . . mɪstʃɹəs æliz. ʌðɝ θɪŋz, θɪŋz aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd, tu, bʌɾ aɪ noʊ wʌt ðət minz. ʃi woʊn ɹəfjuz ɪt."

"When I look at her, I see the same as when I look at . . . Mistress Alys. Other things, things I don't understand, too, but I know what that means. She won't refuse it."

"ðɪs ɪz ɔl fulɪʃnəs," ɹænd sɛɾ ənkʌmftəbli. hɪz hɛdeɪk wɑz feɪɾɪŋ tə nʌmnəs; hɪz hɛd fɛl pækt wɪð wʊl. hi wɑntəd tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðɪs ɡɝl ən ðə θɪŋz ʃi sɔ. ən jɛt. . . . "wʌt dʒju si wən jə lʊk ət . . . ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs?"

"This is all foolishness," Rand said uncomfortably. His headache was fading to numbness; his head felt packed with wool. He wanted to get away from this girl and the things she saw. And yet. . . . "What do you see when you look at . . . the rest of us?"

"ɔl sɔɹts ə θɪŋz," mɪn sɛd, wɪð ə ɡɹɪn əz ɪf ʃi nu wʌɾ i ɹɪli wɑntəd tə æsk. "ðə wɔɹ . . . ɑ . . . mæstɝ ænʒɹə hæz sɛvən ɹuən taʊɝz ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd, ən ə beɪb ɪn ə kɹeɪɾəl hoʊldɪŋ ə sɔɹd, ænd. . . ." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "mɛn laɪk ɪm - jə ʌndɝstænd? - ɔlweɪz əv soʊ mɛni ɪmədʒəz ðeɪ kɹaʊd wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst ɪmədʒəz ɝaʊn ðə ɡlimən ɑɹ ə mæn - nɑɾ ɪm - dʒʌɡəlɪŋ faɪɝ, ən ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ən ðət dʌzn meɪk ɛni sɛns əɾ ɔl fəɹ ə mæn. ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəs θɪŋz aɪ si əbaʊt ðə bɪɡ, kɝli-hɛɹd fɛloʊ ɑɹ ə wʊlf, ən ə bɹoʊkən kɹaʊn, ən tʃɹiz flaʊɝɪŋ ɔl ɝaʊn hɪm. ən ði ʌðɝ wʌn - ə ɹɛɾ iɡəl, ən aɪ ɑn ə bæləns skeɪl, ə dæɡɝ wɪð ə ɹubi, ə hɔɹn, ən ə læfɪŋ feɪs. ðəɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝ θɪŋz, bʌt jə si wʌɾ aɪ min. ðɪs taɪm aɪ kæn meɪk ʌp əɹ daʊn aʊɾ ʌv ɛni ʌv ɪt." ʃi weɪɾəd ðɛn, stɪl ɡɹɪnɪŋ, əntɪl i faɪnəli klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ən æskt.

"All sorts of things," Min said, with a grin as if she knew what he really wanted to ask. "The War . . . ah . . . Master Andra has seven ruined towers around his head, and a babe in a cradle holding a sword, and. . . ." She shook her head. "Men like him - you understand? - always have so many images they crowd one another. The strongest images around the gleeman are a man - not him - juggling fire, and the White Tower, and that doesn't make any sense at all for a man. The strongest things I see about the big, curly-haired fellow are a wolf, and a broken crown, and trees flowering all around him. And the other one - a red eagle, an eye on a balance scale, a dagger with a ruby, a horn, and a laughing face. There are other things, but you see what I mean. This time I can't make up or down out of any of it." She waited then, still grinning, until he finally cleared his throat and asked.

"wʌɾ əbaʊt mi?"

"What about me?"

hɝ ɡɹɪn stɑp dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ʌv aʊtʃɹaɪt læftɝ. "ðə seɪm kaɪndə θɪŋz əz ðə ɹɛst. ə sɔɹd ðəɾ ɪzən ə sɔɹd, ə ɡoʊldən kɹaʊn ə lɔɹəl livz, ə bɛɡɝz stæf, jə pɔɹɪŋ wɔɾɝ ɑn sænd, ə blʌɾi hæn ən ə waɪt-hɑɾ aɪɝn, θɹi wɪmən stændɪŋ oʊvɝ ə fjunɝəl biɹ wɪð jə ɑn ɪt, blæk ɹɑk wɛt wɪð blʌd - "

Her grin stopped just short of outright laughter. "The same kind of things as the rest. A sword that isn't a sword, a golden crown of laurel leaves, a beggar's staff, you pouring water on sand, a bloody hand and a white-hot iron, three women standing over a funeral bier with you on it, black rock wet with blood - "

"ɔl ɹaɪt," hi bɹoʊk ɪn ənizəli. "ju doʊn əv tə lɪst ɪɾ ɔl."

"All right," he broke in uneasily. "You don't have to list it all."

"moʊst ʌv ɔl, aɪ si laɪtnɪŋ ɝaʊn ju, səm stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ət ju, səm kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə ju. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɛni ʌv ɪt minz, ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ. jə ən əl miɾ əɡɛn." ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə kwɪtsɪkəl lʊk, əz ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðəɾ iðɝ.

"Most of all, I see lightning around you, some striking at you, some coming out of you. I don't know what any of it means, except for one thing. You and I will meet again." She gave him a quizzical look, as if she did not understand that either.

"waɪ ʃʊdnt wi?" hi sɛd. "aɪl bi kʌmɪŋ bæk ðɪs weɪ ɑn maɪ weɪ hoʊm."

"Why shouldn't we?" he said. "I'll be coming back this way on my way home."

"aɪ səpoʊz jə wɪl, ət ðæt." sʌɾənli hɝ ɡɹɪn wɑz bæk, ɹaɪ ən mɪstɪɹiəs, ən ʃi pæɾəd ɪz tʃik. "bʌɾ ɪf aɪ toʊl jə ɛvɹiθɪŋ aɪ sɔ, jud bi əz kɝli-hɛɹɾ əz jəɹ fɹɛnd wɪð ðə ʃoʊldɝz."

"I suppose you will, at that." Suddenly her grin was back, wry and mysterious, and she patted his cheek. "But if I told you everything I saw, you'd be as curly-haired as your friend with the shoulders."

hi dʒɝk bæk fɹəm əɹ hæn əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ɹɛd-hɑt. "wʌt dʒju min? dʒju si ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt ɹæts? əɹ dʒɹimz?"

He jerked back from her hand as if it were red-hot. "What do you mean? Do you see anything about rats? Or dreams?"

"ɹæts! noʊ, noʊ ɹæts. əz fəɹ dʒɹimz, meɪbi ɪts jəɹ aɪdiə ʌv ə dʒɹim, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ θɔɾ ɪt wɑz maɪn."

"Rats! No, no rats. As for dreams, maybe it's your idea of a dream, but I never thought it was mine."

hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ʃi wɑz kɹeɪzi, ɡɹɪnɪŋ laɪk ðæt. "aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ," hi sɛd, ɛdʒɪŋ ɝaʊn hɝ. "aɪ . . . aɪ hæv tə mit maɪ fɹɛnz."

He wondered if she was crazy, grinning like that. "I have to go," he said, edging around her. "I . . . I have to meet my friends."

"ɡoʊ, ðɛn. bʌt jə woʊn ɪskeɪp."

"Go, then. But you won't escape."

hi dɪdn ɪɡzækli bɹeɪk ɪndə ə ɹʌn, bʌɾ ɛvɹi stɛp i tʊk wɑz kwɪkɝ ðən ðə stɛp bɪfɔɹ.

He didn't exactly break into a run, but every step he took was quicker than the step before.

"ɹʌn, ɪf jə wɑnt," ʃi kɔld æftɝ hɪm. "ju kæn ɪskeɪp fɹəm mi." hɝ læftɝ spɛɾ ɪm əkɹɔs ðə steɪbliɑɹɾ ən aʊɾ ɪndə ðə stʃɹit, ɪndə ðə hʌbəb ə pipəl. hɝ læst wɝdz wɝ tu kloʊz tə wʌt bælzəmən hæd sɛd. hi blʌndɝɾ ɪndə pipəl əz i hɝid θɹu ðə kɹaʊd, ɝnɪŋ hɑɹd lʊks ən hɑɹd wɝdz, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt sloʊ daʊn əntɪl i wɑz sɛvɹəl stʃɹits əweɪ fɹəm ði ɪn.

"Run, if you want," she called after him. "You can't escape from me." Her laughter sped him across the stableyard and out into the street, into the hubbub of people. Her last words were too close to what Ba'alzamon had said. He blundered into people as he hurried through the crowd, earning hard looks and hard words, but he did not slow down until he was several streets away from the inn.

æftɝ ə taɪm i bɪɡæn tə peɪ ətɛnʃən əɡɛn tə wɛɹ i wɑz. hɪz hɛd fɛlt laɪk ə bəlun, bʌɾ i stɛɹɾ ən ɛndʒɔɪɾ ɛniweɪ. hi θɔt bɛɹlən wɑz ə ɡɹæn sɪɾi, ɪf nɑɾ ɪɡzækli ɪn ðə seɪm weɪ əz sɪɾiz ɪn tɑmz stɔɹiz. hi wɑndɝɾ ʌp bɹɔd stʃɹits, moʊs peɪvd wɪð flæɡstoʊn, ən daʊn nɛɹoʊ, twɪstɪŋ leɪnz, wɛɹɛvɝ tʃæns ən ðə ʃɪftɪŋ ə ðə kɹaʊd tʊk hɪm. ɪt hæd ɹeɪn dʊɹɪŋ ðə naɪt, ən ðə stʃɹits ðət wɝ ənpeɪv hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn tʃɝn tə mʌd baɪ ðə kɹaʊdz, bʌt mʌɾi stʃɹits wɝ nʌθɪŋ nu tə hɪm. nʌn ə ðə stʃɹits ɪn ɛmənz fild wɑz peɪvd.

After a time he began to pay attention again to where he was. His head felt like a balloon, but he stared and enjoyed anyway. He thought Baerlon was a grand city, if not exactly in the same way as cities in Thom's stories. He wandered up broad streets, most paved with flagstone, and down narrow, twisting lanes, wherever chance and the shifting of the crowd took him. It had rained during the night, and the streets that were unpaved had already been churned to mud by the crowds, but muddy streets were nothing new to him. None of the streets in Emond's Field was paved.

ðəɹ sɝɾənli wɝ noʊ pæləsəz, ən oʊnli ə fju haʊsəz wɝ vɛɹi mʌtʃ bɪɡɝ ðən ðoʊz bæk hoʊm, bʌɾ ɛvɹi haʊs hæɾ ə ɹuf ə sleɪɾ əɹ taɪl əz faɪn əz ðə ɹuf ə ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn. hi səpoʊz ðəɹ wəd bi ə pæləs əɹ tu ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. əz fəɹ ɪnz, hi kaʊntəd naɪn, nɑt wʌn smɔlɝ ðən ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ən moʊst əz lɑɹdʒ əz ðə stæɡ ən laɪən, ən ðəɹ wɝ plɛnti ʌv stʃɹits i hæd nɑt sin jɛt.

There certainly were no palaces, and only a few houses were very much bigger than those back home, but every house had a roof of slate or tile as fine as the roof of the Winespring Inn. He supposed there would be a palace or two in Caemlyn. As for inns, he counted nine, not one smaller than the Winespring and most as large as the Stag and Lion, and there were plenty of streets he had not seen yet.

ʃɑps dɑɾəd ɛvɹi stʃɹit, wɪð ɔnɪŋz aʊt fɹʌnt ʃɛltɝɪŋ teɪbəlz kʌvɝd wɪð ɡʊdz, ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɹəm klɔθ tə bʊks tə pɑts tə buts. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ə hʌnʒɹəd pɛdlɝz' wæɡənz hæd spɪld aʊt ðɛɹ kɑntɛns. hi stɛɹd soʊ mʌtʃ ðət mɔɹ ðən wʌns i hæd tə hɝi ɑn ət ðə səspɪʃəs lʊk ʌv ə ʃɑpkipɝ. hi hæd nɑɾ ʌndɝstʊd ðə fɝst ʃɑpkipɝz stɛɹ. wən i dɪɾ ʌndɝstænd, hi stɑɹɾəd tə ɡɛɾ æŋɡɹi əntɪl i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət hɪɹ i wɑz ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ. hi kəd nɑɾ əv bɑt mʌtʃ, ɛniweɪ. hi ɡæspt wən i sɔ haʊ mɛni kɑpɝz wɝ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd fəɹ ə dʌzən dɪskʌlɝɾ æpəlz əɹ ə hændfʊl ə ʃɹɪvəl tɝnəps, ðə sɔɹt ðət wəd bi fɛd tə ðə hɔɹsəz ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, bʌt pipəl simd iɡɝ tə peɪ.

Shops dotted every street, with awnings out front sheltering tables covered with goods, everything from cloth to books to pots to boots. It was as if a hundred peddlers' wagons had spilled out their contents. He stared so much that more than once he had to hurry on at the suspicious look of a shopkeeper. He had not understood the first shopkeeper's stare. When he did understand, he started to get angry until he remembered that here he was the stranger. He could not have bought much, anyway. He gasped when he saw how many coppers were exchanged for a dozen discolored apples or a handful of shriveled turnips, the sort that would be fed to the horses in the Two Rivers, but people seemed eager to pay.

ðəɹ wɝ sɝɾənli mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf pipəl, tə hɪz ɛstəmeɪʃən. fəɹ ə waɪl ðə ʃɪɹ nʌmbɝ ə ðɛm ɔlmoʊst oʊvɝwɛlm hɪm. səm wɔɹ kloʊðz ə faɪnɝ kʌt ðən ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz - ɔlmoʊst əz faɪn əz mɔɪɹeɪnz - ən kwaɪɾ ə fju hæd lɔŋ, fɝ-laɪn koʊts ðət flæpt ɝaʊn ðɛɹ æŋkəlz. ðə maɪnɝz ɛvɹibɑɾi ət ði ɪn kɛp tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, ðeɪ hæd ðə hʌntʃt lʊk ə mɛn u ɡɹʌbd ʌndɝɡɹaʊnd. bʌt moʊst ə ðə pipəl dɪd nɑt lʊk ɛni dɪfɹən fɹəm ðoʊz i hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp wɪð, nɑɾ ɪn dʒɹɛs əɹ ɪn feɪs. hi hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd ðeɪ wʊd, sʌmhaʊ. ɪndid, səm ə ðɛm hæd soʊ mʌtʃ ðə lʊk ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɪn ðɛɹ feɪsəz ðəɾ i kəɾ ɪmædʒən ðeɪ bɪlɔŋ tə wʌn fæmli əɹ ənʌðɝ ðəɾ i nu ɝaʊn ɛmənz fild. ə tuθləs, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd fɛloʊ wɪð ɪɹz laɪk dʒʌɡ hændəlz, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ə bɛntʃ aʊtsaɪd wʌn ə ði ɪnz ən piɹɪŋ mɔɹnfəli ɪndə ən ɛmpti tæŋkɝd, kəɾ izəli hæv bɪn bili kɔŋɡɝz kloʊs kʌzən. ðə læntɝn-dʒɔd teɪlɝ soʊɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz ʃɑp maɪɾ əv bɪn dʒɑn θeɪnz bɹʌðɝ, ivən tə ðə seɪm bɔl spɑɾ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd. ə nɪɹ mɪɹɝ ɪmədʒ ə səmɛl kɹeɪ pʊʃt pæst ɹænd əz i tɝn ə kɔɹnɝ, ænd. . . .

There were certainly more than enough people, to his estimation. For a while the sheer number of them almost overwhelmed him. Some wore clothes of finer cut than anyone in the Two Rivers - almost as fine as Moiraine's - and quite a few had long, fur-lined coats that flapped around their ankles. The miners everybody at the inn kept talking about, they had the hunched look of men who grubbed underground. But most of the people did not look any different from those he had grown up with, not in dress or in face. He had expected they would, somehow. Indeed, some of them had so much the look of the Two Rivers in their faces that he could imagine they belonged to one family or another that he knew around Emond's Field. A toothless, gray-haired fellow with ears like jug handles, sitting on a bench outside one of the inns and peering mournfully into an empty tankard, could easily have been Bili Congar's close cousin. The lantern-jawed tailor sewing in front of his shop might have been Jon Thane's brother, even to the same bald spot on the back of his head. A near mirror image of Samel Crawe pushed past Rand as he turned a corner, and. . . .

ɪn dɪsbɪlif i stɛɹɾ əɾ ə boʊni lɪɾəl mæn wɪð lɔŋ ɑɹmz ən ə bɪɡ noʊz, ʃʌvɪŋ hɝidli θɹu ðə kɹaʊɾ ɪn kloʊðz ðət lʊk laɪk ə bʌndəl ə ɹæɡz. ðə mænz aɪz wɝ sʌŋkən ən ɪz dɝɾi feɪs ɡɔnt, əz ɪf i hæd nɑɾ iɾən əɹ slɛpt ɪn deɪz, bʌt ɹænd kəd swɛɹ. . . . ðə ɹæɡəd mæn sɔ hɪm ðɛn, ən fɹoʊz ɪn mɪd-stɛp, hidləs ə pipəl u ɔl bʌt stʌmbəld oʊvɝ hɪm. ðə læs daʊɾ ɪn ɹændz maɪn vænɪʃt.

In disbelief he stared at a bony little man with long arms and a big nose, shoving hurriedly through the crowd in clothes that looked like a bundle of rags. The man's eyes were sunken and his dirty face gaunt, as if he had not eaten or slept in days, but Rand could swear. . . . The ragged man saw him then, and froze in mid-step, heedless of people who all but stumbled over him. The last doubt in Rand's mind vanished.

"mæstɝ feɪn!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. "wi ɔl θɔt jə wɝ - "

"Master Fain!" he shouted. "We all thought you were - "

əz kwɪk əz ə blɪŋk ðə pɛdlɝ dɑɹɾɪd əweɪ, bʌt ɹænd dɑdʒd æftɝ hɪm, kɔlɪŋ əpɑlədʒiz oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ tə ðə pipəl i bʌmpt. θɹu ðə kɹaʊɾ i dʒʌs kɑt saɪɾ ə feɪn dæʃɪŋ ɪndə ən æliweɪ, ən i tɝn æftɝ.

As quick as a blink the peddler darted away, but Rand dodged after him, calling apologies over his shoulder to the people he bumped. Through the crowd he just caught sight of Fain dashing into an alleyway, and he turned after.

ə fju stɛps ɪndə ði æliweɪ ðə pɛdlɝ hæd stɑpt ɪn ɪz tʃɹæks. ə tɔl fɛns meɪɾ ɪɾ ɪndə ə dɛɾ ɛnd. əz ɹænd skɪɾəd tə ə hɔlt, feɪn ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn hɪm, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ wɛɹəli ən bækɪŋ əweɪ. hi flæpt ɡɹaɪmi hænz ət ɹænd tə steɪ bæk. mɔɹ ðən wʌn ɹɪp ʃoʊɾ ɪn ɪz koʊt, ən ɪz kloʊk wɑz wɔɹn ən tæɾɝd əz ɪf ɪt hæd sin mʌtʃ hɑɹɾɝ juz ðən ɪt wɑz mɛn fɔɹ.

A few steps into the alleyway the peddler had stopped in his tracks. A tall fence made it into a dead end. As Rand skidded to a halt, Fain rounded on him, crouching warily and backing away. He flapped grimy hands at Rand to stay back. More than one rip showed in his coat, and his cloak was worn and tattered as if it had seen much harder use than it was meant for.

"mæstɝ feɪn?" ɹænd sɛd hɛzɪɾəntli. "wʌɾ ɪz ðə mæɾɝ? ɪts mi, ɹænd ælθɹ, fɹəm ɛmənz fild. wi ɔl θɔt ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd teɪkən ju."

"Master Fain?" Rand said hesitantly. "What is the matter? It's me, Rand al'Thor, from Emond's Field. We all thought the Trollocs had taken you."

feɪn dʒɛstʃɝd ʃɑɹpli ænd, stɪl ɪn ə kɹaʊtʃ, ɹæn ə fju kɹæb stɛps təwɔɹd ði oʊpən ɛn ə ði æli. hi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə pæs ɹænd, əɹ ivən kʌm kloʊs tə hɪm. "doʊnt!" hi ɹæspt. hɪz hɛd ʃɪftəd kɑnstənli əz i tʃɹaɪd tə si ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹit bɪɑn ɹænd. "doʊn mɛnʃən" - hɪz vɔɪs dʒɹɑp tə ə hɔɹs wɪspɝ, ən i tɝn ɪz hɛɾ əweɪ, wɑtʃɪŋ ɹænd wɪð kwɪk, saɪɾɛlɔŋ ɡlænsɪz - "ðɛm. ðəɹ bi waɪtkloʊks ɪn ðə taʊn."

Fain gestured sharply and, still in a crouch, ran a few crabbed steps toward the open end of the alley. He did not try to pass Rand, or even come close to him. "Don't!" he rasped. His head shifted constantly as he tried to see everything in the street beyond Rand. "Don't mention" - his voice dropped to a hoarse whisper, and he turned his head away, watching Rand with quick, sidelong glances - "them. There be Whitecloaks in the town."

"ðeɪ hæv noʊ ɹizən tə bɑðɝ ʌs," ɹænd sɛd. "kʌm bæk tə ðə stæɡ ən laɪən wɪð mi. aɪm steɪɪŋ ðəɹ wɪð fɹɛnz. jə noʊ moʊst ə ðɛm. ðəl bi ɡlæd tə si ju. wi ɔl θɔt jə wɝ dɛd."

"They have no reason to bother us," Rand said. "Come back to the Stag and Lion with me. I'm staying there with friends. You know most of them. They'll be glad to see you. We all thought you were dead."

"dɛd?" ðə pɛdlɝ snæpt ɪndɪɡnənli. "nɑt pdən feɪn. pdən feɪn noʊz wɪtʃ weɪ tə dʒʌmp ən wɛɹ tə lænd." hi stʃɹeɪɾənd ɪz ɹæɡz əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ fistdeɪ kloʊðz. "ɔlweɪz hæv, ən ɔlweɪz wɪl. əl lɪv ə lɔŋ taɪm. lɔŋɡɝ ðən - " əbɹʌpli hɪz feɪs taɪɾənd ən ɪz hænz klʌtʃt hoʊld ə hɪz koʊt fɹʌnt. "ðeɪ bɝn maɪ wæɡən, ən ɔl maɪ ɡʊdz. hæd noʊ kɑz tə bi duɪŋ ðæt, dɪd ðeɪ? aɪ kʊdnt ɡɛt tə maɪ hɔɹsəz. maɪ hɔɹsəz, bʌt ðət fæɾ oʊld ɪnkipɝ hæɾ əm lɑkt ʌp ɪn ɪz steɪbəl. aɪ hæd tə stɛp kwɪk nɑt tə ɡɛt maɪ θɹoʊt slɪt, ən wʌɾ ɪt ɡɛt mi? ɔl ðəɾ aɪv ɡɑt lɛft ɪz wʌɾ aɪ stæn ʌp ɪn. naʊ, ɪz ðət fɛɹ? ɪz ɪt, naʊ?"
