tɑm snɔɹɾɪd ən blu aʊɾ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz. "wʌɾ ɪz tə stɑp əm fɹəm hævɪŋ sʌmwʌn, sʌmθɪŋ, ət waɪtbɹɪdʒ ɔlɹɛɾi?"

Thom snorted and blew out his mustaches. "What is to stop them from having someone, something, at Whitebridge already?"

fɹəm ðə wɛs keɪm ðə kinɪŋ weɪl ʌv ə hɔɹn. lænz hɛd wɪpt ɝaʊn tə stɛɹ bæk daʊn ðə ɹoʊd bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ɹænd fɛlt ə tʃɪl. ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm ɹɪmeɪn kɑm ɪnʌf tə θɪŋk, tɛn maɪlz, noʊ mɔɹ.

From the west came the keening wail of a horn. Lan's head whipped around to stare back down the road behind them. Rand felt a chill. A part of him remained calm enough to think, ten miles, no more.

"nʌθɪŋ stɑps ðɛm, ɡlimən," ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd. "wi tʃɹʌs tə ðə laɪɾ ən lʌk. bʌt naʊ wi noʊ fəɹ sɝɾən ðəɹ ɑɹ tʃɹɑləks bɪhaɪn ʌs."

"Nothing stops them, gleeman," the Warder said. "We trust to the Light and luck. But now we know for certain there are Trollocs behind us."

mɔɪɹeɪn dʌstɪɾ əɹ hænz. "ɪɾ ɪz taɪm fəɹ əs tə muv ɑn." ði ɛɛs sədaɪ maʊntəɾ əɹ waɪt mɛɹ.

Moiraine dusted her hands. "It is time for us to move on." The Aes Sedai mounted her white mare.

ðət sɛɾ ɔf ə skɹæmbəl fəɹ ðə hɔɹsəz, spiɾɪd baɪ ə sɛkənd waɪndɪŋ ə ðə hɔɹn. ðɪs taɪm ʌðɝz ænsɝd, ðə θɪn saʊnz floʊɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə wɛs laɪk ə dɝdʒ. ɹænd meɪd ɹɛɾi tə pʊt klaʊd tə ə ɡæləp ɹaɪɾ əweɪ, ən ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls sɛɾəld ðɛɹ ɹeɪnz wɪð ðə seɪm ɝdʒənsi. ɛvɹiwʌn ɪksɛp læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn. ðə wɔɹɾɝ ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə lɔŋ lʊk.

That set off a scramble for the horses, speeded by a second winding of the horn. This time others answered, the thin sounds floating out of the west like a dirge. Rand made ready to put Cloud to a gallop right away, and everyone else settled their reins with the same urgency. Everyone except Lan and Moiraine. The Warder and the Aes Sedai exchanged a long look.

"kip əm muvɪŋ, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ," læn sɛd faɪnəli. "aɪ wɪl ɹɪtɝn əz sun əz aɪm eɪbəl. jəl noʊ ɪf aɪ feɪl." pʊɾɪŋ ə hæn ɑn mændɑɹbz sæɾəl, hi vɔltəd tə ðə bæk ə ðə blæk stæljən ən ɡæləp daʊn ðə hɪl. hɛɾɪŋ wɛst. ðə hɔɹnz saʊndəɾ əɡɛn.

"Keep them moving, Moiraine Sedai," Lan said finally. "I will return as soon as I am able. You will know if I fail." Putting a hand on Mandarb's saddle, he vaulted to the back of the black stallion and galloped down the hill. Heading west. The horns sounded again.

"ðə laɪt ɡoʊ wɪð ju, læs lɔɹɾ ə ðə sɛvən taʊɝz," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛɾ ɔlmoʊs tu sɔfli fəɹ ɹænd tə hɪɹ. dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ʃi tɝn ɑldib tə ði ist. "wi mʌst ɡoʊ ɑn," ʃi sɛd, ən stɑɹɾəd ɔf əɾ ə sloʊ, stɛɾi tʃɹɑt. ði ʌðɝz fɑloʊɾ əɹ ɪn ə taɪt faɪl.

"The Light go with you, last Lord of the Seven Towers," Moiraine said almost too softly for Rand to hear. Drawing a deep breath, she turned Aldieb to the east. "We must go on," she said, and started off at a slow, steady trot. The others followed her in a tight file.

ɹænd twɪstəd wʌns ɪn ɪz sæɾəl tə lʊk fəɹ læn, bʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi lɔs tə saɪɾ əmʌŋ ðə loʊ hɪlz ən lifləs tʃɹiz. læs lɔɹɾ ə ðə sɛvən taʊɝz, ʃi hæd kɔl hɪm. hi wʌndɝd wʌt ðət mɛnt. hi hæd nɑt θɔɾ ɛniwʌn bɪsaɪdz hɪmsɛlf hæd hɝd, bʌt tɑm wɑz tʃuɪŋ ði ɛnz ə hɪz mʌstæʃɪz, ən i hæɾ ə spɛkjələɾɪv fɹaʊn ɑn ɪz feɪs. ðə ɡlimən sim tə noʊ ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni θɪŋz.

Rand twisted once in his saddle to look for Lan, but the Warder was already lost to sight among the low hills and leafless trees. Last Lord of the Seven Towers, she had called him. He wondered what that meant. He had not thought anyone besides himself had heard, but Thom was chewing the ends of his mustaches, and he had a speculative frown on his face. The gleeman seemed to know a great many things.

ðə hɔɹnz kɔld ən ænsɝd wʌns mɔɹ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ɹænd ʃɪftəɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl. ðeɪ wɝ kloʊsɝ ðɪs taɪm; hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt. eɪt maɪlz. meɪbi sɛvən. mæt ən ɛɡwin lʊkt oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ən pɛɹɪn hʌntʃt əz ɪf i ɪkspɛktəd sʌmθɪŋ tə hɪɾ ɪm ɪn ðə bæk. nɪneɪiv ɹoʊɾ ʌp tə spik tə mɔɪɹeɪn.

The horns called and answered once more behind them. Rand shifted in his saddle. They were closer this time; he was sure of it. Eight miles. Maybe seven. Mat and Egwene looked over their shoulders, and Perrin hunched as if he expected something to hit him in the back. Nynaeve rode up to speak to Moiraine.

"kænt wi ɡoʊ ɛni fæstɝ?" ʃi æskt. "ðoʊz hɔɹnz ɑɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ kloʊsɝ."

"Can't we go any faster?" she asked. "Those horns are getting closer."

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ænd waɪ də ðeɪ lɛɾ əs noʊ ðeɪ ɑɹ ðɛɹ? pɝhæps soʊ wɪl hɝi ɑn wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv wʌt maɪt bi əhɛd."

The Aes Sedai shook her head. "And why do they let us know they are there? Perhaps so we will hurry on without thinking of what might be ahead."

ðeɪ kɛpt ɑn ət ðə seɪm stɛɾi peɪs. əɾ ɪntɝvəlz ðə hɔɹnz ɡeɪv kɹaɪ bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ən itʃ taɪm ðə saʊnd wɑz kloʊsɝ. ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ ə haʊ kloʊs, bʌt ðə θɔt keɪm ənbɪddən əɾ ɛvɹi bɹeɪzən weɪl. faɪv maɪlz, hi wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ æŋkʃəsli, wən læn sʌɾənli bɝst ɝaʊn ðə hɪl bɪhaɪn əm əɾ ə ɡæləp.

They kept on at the same steady pace. At intervals the horns gave cry behind them, and each time the sound was closer. Rand tried to stop thinking of how close, but the thought came unbidden at every brazen wail. Five miles, he was thinking anxiously, when Lan suddenly burst around the hill behind them at a gallop.

hi keɪm əbɹɛst ə mɔɪɹeɪn, ɹeɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə stæljən. "æt lis θɹi fɪsts ə tʃɹɑləks, itʃ lɛd baɪ ə hæfmən. meɪbi faɪv."

He came abreast of Moiraine, reining in the stallion. "At least three fists of Trollocs, each led by a Halfman. Maybe five."

"ɪf jə wɝ kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si ðɛm," ɛɡwin sɛd wɝidli, "ðeɪ cʊɾə sin ju. ðeɪ kəd bi ɹaɪɾ ɑn jəɹ hilz."

"If you were close enough to see them," Egwene said worriedly, "they could have seen you. They could be right on your heels."

"hi wɑz nɑt sin." nɪneɪiv dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp əz ɛvɹiwʌn lʊkt ət hɝ. "aɪ hæv fɑloʊɾ ɪz tʃɹeɪl, ɹɪmɛmbɝ."

"He was not seen." Nynaeve drew herself up as everyone looked at her. "I have followed his trail, remember."

"hʌʃ," mɔɪɹeɪn kəmændəd. "læn ɪz tɛlɪŋ əs ðəɹ ɑɹ pɝhæps faɪv hʌnʒɹəd tʃɹɑləks bɪhaɪn ʌs." ə stʌn saɪləns fɑloʊd, ðən læn spoʊk əɡɛn.

"Hush," Moiraine commanded. "Lan is telling us there are perhaps five hundred Trollocs behind us." A stunned silence followed, then Lan spoke again.

"æn ðeɪ ɑɹ kloʊzɪŋ ðə ɡæp. ðəl bi ɑn əs ɪn ən aʊɝ əɹ lɛs."

"And they are closing the gap. They will be on us in an hour or less."

hæf tə hɝsɛlf, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd, "ɪf ðeɪ hæd ðət mɛni bɪfɔɹ, waɪ wɝ ðeɪ nɑt juzd əɾ ɛmənz fild? ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt, haʊ dɪd ðeɪ kʌm hɪɹ sɪns?"

Half to herself, the Aes Sedai said, "If they had that many before, why were they not used at Emond's Field? If they did not, how did they come here since?"

"ðeɪ ɑɹ spɹɛɾ aʊt tə dʒɹaɪv əs bɪfɔɹ ðɛm," læn sɛd, "wɪð skaʊts kɔɹɾɝɪŋ əhɛɾ ə ðə meɪn pɑɹɾiz."

"They are spread out to drive us before them," Lan said, "with scouts quartering ahead of the main parties."

"dʒɹaɪvɪŋ əs təwɔɹd wʌt?" mɔɪɹeɪn mjuzd. əz ɪf tə ænsɝ əɹ ə hɔɹn saʊndəɾ ɪn ðə dɪstəns tə ðə wɛst, ə lɔŋ moʊn ðət wɑz ænsɝd ðɪs taɪm baɪ ʌðɝz, ɔl əhɛɾ ə ðɛm. mɔɪɹeɪn stɑpt ɑldib; ði ʌðɝz fɑloʊɾ əɹ lɛd, tɑm ən ði ɛmənz fil foʊk lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn fɪɹfəli. hɔɹnz kɹaɪɾ aʊt bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, ən bɪhaɪnd. ɹænd θɔt ðeɪ hɛld ə noʊɾ ə tʃɹaɪəmf.

"Driving us toward what?" Moiraine mused. As if to answer her a horn sounded in the distance to the west, a long moan that was answered this time by others, all ahead of them. Moiraine stopped Aldieb; the others followed her lead, Thom and the Emond's Field folk looking around fearfully. Horns cried out before them, and behind. Rand thought they held a note of triumph.

"wʌt də wi də naʊ?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəɾ æŋɡɹəli. "wɛɹ də wi ɡoʊ?"

"What do we do now?" Nynaeve demanded angrily. "Where do we go?"

"ɔl ðəɾ ɪz lɛft ɪz nɔɹθ əɹ saʊθ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, mɔɹ θɪŋkɪŋ əlaʊd ðən ænsɝɪŋ ðə wɪzdəm. "tə ðə saʊθ ɑɹ ðə hɪlz ʌv æbʃɝ, bæɹən ən dɛd, ən ðə tɛɹən, wɪð noʊ weɪ tə kɹɔs, ən noʊ tʃɹæfɪk baɪ boʊt. tə ðə nɔɹθ, wi kən ɹitʃ ði ɑɹɪnɛl bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl, ən ðəɹ wɪl bi ə tʃæns ʌv ə tʃɹeɪɾɝz boʊt. ɪf ði aɪs əz bɹoʊkən ət mɛɹədɑn."

"All that is left is north or south," Moiraine said, more thinking aloud than answering the Wisdom. "To the south are the Hills of Absher, barren and dead, and the Taren, with no way to cross, and no traffic by boat. To the north, we can reach the Arinelle before nightfall, and there will be a chance of a trader's boat. If the ice has broken at Maradon."

"ðɛɹ ɪz ə pleɪs ðə tʃɹɑləks wɪl nɑt ɡoʊ," læn sɛd, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪnz hɛd wɪpt ɝaʊnd ʃɑɹpli.

"There is a place the Trollocs will not go," Lan said, but Moiraine's head whipped around sharply.

"noʊ!" ʃi moʊʃən tə ðə wɔɹɾɝ, ən i pʊɾ ɪz hɛd kloʊs tə hɝz soʊ ðɛɹ tɔk kəd nɑt bi oʊvɝhɝd.

"No!" She motioned to the Warder, and he put his head close to hers so their talk could not be overheard.

ðə hɔɹnz wɪndɪd, ən ɹændz hɔɹs dæns nɝvəsli.

The horns winded, and Rand's horse danced nervously.

"ðeɪɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɹaɪɾən ʌs," tɑm ɡɹaʊld, ətɛmptɪŋ tə stɛɾi hɪz maʊnt. hi saʊndəd hæf æŋɡɹi ən hæf əz ɪf ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ səksiɾɪŋ. "ðeɪɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə skɛɹ əs əntɪl wi pænɪk ən ɹʌn. ðəl əv ʌs, ðɛn."

"They're trying to frighten us," Thom growled, attempting to steady his mount. He sounded half angry and half as if the Trollocs were succeeding. "They're trying to scare us until we panic and run. They'll have us, then."

ɛɡwinz hɛd swʌŋ wɪð ɛvɹi blæst ʌv ə hɔɹn, stɛɹɪŋ fɝst əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, ðən bɪhaɪnd, əz ɪf lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ðə fɝs tʃɹɑləks. ɹænd wɑntəd tə də ðə seɪm θɪŋ, bʌɾ i tʃɹaɪd tə haɪɾ ɪt. hi muv klaʊd kloʊsɝ tə hɝ.

Egwene's head swung with every blast of a horn, staring first ahead of them, then behind, as if looking for the first Trollocs. Rand wanted to do the same thing, but he tried to hide it. He moved Cloud closer to her.

"wi ɡoʊ nɔɹθ," mɔɪɹeɪn ənaʊnst.

"We go north," Moiraine announced.

ðə hɔɹnz kind ʃɹɪli əz ðeɪ lɛf ðə ɹoʊɾ ən tʃɹɑɾəd ɪndə ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ hɪlz.

The horns keened shrilly as they left the road and trotted into the surrounding hills.

ðə hɪlz wɝ loʊ, bʌt ðə weɪ wɑz ɔl ʌp ən daʊn, wɪð nɛvɝ ə flæt stʃɹɛtʃ, bɪniθ bɛɹ-bɹæntʃt tʃɹiz ən θɹu dɛɾ ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ. ðə hɔɹsəz klaɪm ləbɔɹiəsli ʌp wʌn sloʊp oʊnli tə kæntɝ daʊn ði ʌðɝ. læn sɛɾ ə hɑɹd peɪs, fæstɝ ðən ðeɪ hæd juzd ɑn ðə ɹoʊd.

The hills were low, but the way was all up and down, with never a flat stretch, beneath bare-branched trees and through dead undergrowth. The horses climbed laboriously up one slope only to canter down the other. Lan set a hard pace, faster than they had used on the road.

bɹæntʃəz læʃt ɹænd əkɹɔs ðə feɪs ən tʃɛst. oʊl kɹipɝz ən vaɪnz kɑɾ ɪz ɑɹmz, ən səmtaɪmz snæɡd ɪz fʊt ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə stɝəp. ðə kinɪŋ hɔɹnz keɪm ɛvɝ kloʊsɝ, ən ɛvɝ mɔɹ fɹikwənli.

Branches lashed Rand across the face and chest. Old creepers and vines caught his arms, and sometimes snagged his foot right out of the stirrup. The keening horns came ever closer, and ever more frequently.

əz hɑɹɾ əz læn pʊʃt ðɛm, ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ɡɛɾɪŋ fɑɹðɝ ɑn vɛɹi kwɪkli. ðeɪ tʃɹævəl tu fiɾ ʌp əɹ daʊn fəɹ ɛvɹi wʌn fɔɹwɝd, ən ɛvɹi fʊt wɑz ə skɹæmbəlɪŋ ɛfɝt. ən ðə hɔɹnz wɝ kʌmɪŋ nɪɹɝ. tu maɪlz, hi θɔt. meɪbi lɛs.

As hard as Lan pushed them, they were not getting farther on very quickly. They traveled two feet up or down for every one forward, and every foot was a scrambling effort. And the horns were coming nearer. Two miles, he thought. Maybe less.

æftɝ ə taɪm læn bɪɡæn piɹɪŋ fɝst wʌn weɪ ðən ənʌðɝ, ðə hɑɹd pleɪnz ə hɪz feɪs əz kloʊs tə wɝi əz ɹænd hæd sin ðɛm. wʌns ðə wɔɹɾɝ stʊɾ ɪn ɪz stɝəps tə stɛɹ bæk ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd kʌm. ɔl ɹænd kəd si wɝ tʃɹiz. læn sɛɾəld bæk ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl ən ʌnkɑnʃəsli pʊʃt bæk ɪz kloʊk tə klɪɹ ɪz sɔɹɾ əz i ɹɪzum sɝtʃɪŋ ðə fɔɹəst.

After a time Lan began peering first one way then another, the hard planes of his face as close to worry as Rand had seen them. Once the Warder stood in his stirrups to stare back the way they had come. All Rand could see were trees. Lan settled back into his saddle and unconsciously pushed back his cloak to clear his sword as he resumed searching the forest.

ɹænd mɛt mæts aɪ kwɛstʃənɪŋli, bʌt mæt oʊnli ɡɹɪməst ət ðə wɔɹɾɝz bæk ən ʃɹʌɡd hɛlpləsli.

Rand met Mat's eye questioningly, but Mat only grimaced at the Warder's back and shrugged helplessly.

læn spoʊk, ðɛn, oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ tʃɹɑləks nɪɹbaɪ." ðeɪ tɑpt ə hɪl ən stɑɹɾəd daʊn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. "sʌm ə ðə skaʊts, sɛn əhɛɾ ə ðə ɹɛst. pɹɑbli. ɪf wi kʌm ɑn ðɛm, steɪ wɪð mi əɾ ɔl kɑsts, ən də əz aɪ du. wi mʌs kip ɑn ðə weɪ wəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ."

Lan spoke, then, over his shoulder. "There are Trollocs nearby." They topped a hill and started down the other side. "Some of the scouts, sent ahead of the rest. Probably. If we come on them, stay with me at all costs, and do as I do. We must keep on the way we are going."

"blʌɾ ən æʃəz!" tɑm mʌɾɝd. nɪneɪiv moʊʃən tə ɛɡwin tə kip kloʊs.

"Blood and ashes!" Thom muttered. Nynaeve motioned to Egwene to keep close.

skæɾɝd stænz ʌv ɛvɝɡɹinz pɹəvaɪɾəd ði oʊnli ɹil kʌvɝ, bʌt ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə pɪɹ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən ət wʌns, hɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən tɝnɪŋ ɡɹeɪ tʃɹi tʃɹʌŋks kɑɾ aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ ɪndə tʃɹɑləks. ðə hɔɹnz wɝ kloʊsɝ, tu. ən dɝɛkli bɪhaɪn ðɛm. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt. bɪhaɪn ən kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ.

Scattered stands of evergreens provided the only real cover, but Rand tried to peer in every direction at once, his imagination turning gray tree trunks caught out of the corner of his eye into Trollocs. The horns were closer, too. And directly behind them. He was sure of it. Behind and coming closer.

ðeɪ tɑpt ənʌðɝ hɪl.

They topped another hill.

bɪloʊ ðɛm, dʒʌst stɑɹɾɪŋ ʌp ðə sloʊp, mɑɹtʃt tʃɹɑləks kæɹiɪŋ poʊlz tɪpt wɪð ɡɹeɪt lups ə ɹoʊp əɹ lɔŋ hʊks. mɛni tʃɹɑləks. ðə laɪn stʃɹɛtʃt fɑɹ tə iðɝ saɪd, ði ɛnz aʊɾ ə saɪt, bʌɾ əɾ ɪts sɛntɝ, dɝɛkli ɪn fɹʌn ə læn, ə feɪd ɹoʊd.

Below them, just starting up the slope, marched Trollocs carrying poles tipped with great loops of rope or long hooks. Many Trollocs. The line stretched far to either side, the ends out of sight, but at its center, directly in front of Lan, a Fade rode.

ðə mɹdʒɹɑl sim tə hɛzəteɪɾ əz ðə hjumənz əpɪɹɾ ətɑp ðə hɪl, bʌɾ ɪn ðə nɛkst ɪnstən ɪt pɹədust ə sɔɹd wɪð ðə blæk bleɪd ɹænd ɹɪmɛmbɝd soʊ kwizəli, ən weɪvd ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪts hɛd. ðə laɪn ə tʃɹɑləks skɹæmbəl fɔɹwɝd.

The Myrddraal seemed to hesitate as the humans appeared atop the hill, but in the next instant it produced a sword with the black blade Rand remembered so queasily, and waved it over its head. The line of Trollocs scrambled forward.

ivən bɪfɔɹ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl muvd, lænz sɔɹd wɑz ɪn ɪz hænd. "steɪ wɪð mi!" hi kɹaɪd, ən mændɑɹb plʌnʒd daʊn ðə sloʊp təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹɑləks. "fɔɹ ðə sɛvən taʊɝz!" hi ʃaʊɾəd.

Even before the Myrddraal moved, Lan's sword was in his hand. "Stay with me!" he cried, and Mandarb plunged down the slope toward the Trollocs. "For the Seven Towers!" he shouted.

ɹænd ɡʌlpt ən buɾɪd ðə ɡɹeɪ fɔɹwɝd; ðə hoʊl ɡɹup ə ðɛm stʃɹimd æftɝ ðə wɔɹɾɝ. hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə faɪn tæmz sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪz fɪst. kɑɾ ʌp baɪ lænz kɹaɪ, hi faʊn ɪz oʊn. "meɪnɛðɝən! meɪnɛðɝən!"

Rand gulped and booted the gray forward; the whole group of them streamed after the Warder. He was surprised to find Tam's sword in his fist. Caught up by Lan's cry, he found his own. "Manetheren! Manetheren!"

pɛɹɪn tʊk ɪɾ ʌp. "meɪnɛðɝən! meɪnɛðɝən!"

Perrin took it up. "Manetheren! Manetheren!"

bʌt mæt ʃaʊɾəd, "kæɹɑi ən kɑldəzɑɹ! kæɹɑi ən ɛlɪsɑnd! æl ɛlɪsɑnd!"

But Mat shouted, "Carai an Caldazar! Carai an Ellisande! Al Ellisande!"

ðə feɪdz hɛd tɝn fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑləks tə ðə ɹaɪɾɝz tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ təwɔɹd hɪm. ðə blæk sɔɹd fɹoʊz oʊvɝ ɪts hɛd, ən ði oʊpənɪŋ ʌv ɪts kaʊl swɪvəld, sɝtʃɪŋ əmʌŋ ði ɔnkʌmɪŋ hɔɹsmən.

The Fade's head turned from the Trollocs to the riders charging toward him. The black sword froze over its head, and the opening of its cowl swiveled, searching among the oncoming horsemen.

ðən læn wɑz ɑn ðə mɹdʒɹɑl, əz ðə hjumən foʊk fɛl ɑn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk laɪn. wɔɹɾɝz bleɪd mɛt blæk stil fɹəm ðə fɔɹdʒɪz ət θɑkændɑɹ wɪð ə klæŋ laɪk ə ɡɹeɪt bɛl, ðə toʊl ɛkoʊɪŋ ɪn ðə hɑloʊ, ə flæʃ ə blu laɪt fɪlɪŋ ði ɛɹ laɪk ʃit laɪtnɪŋ.

Then Lan was on the Myrddraal, as the human folk fell on the Trolloc line. Warder's blade met black steel from the forges at Thakan'dar with a clang like a great bell, the toll echoing in the hollow, a flash of blue light filling the air like sheet lightning.

bist-mʌzəld ɔlmoʊst-mɛn swɔɹmd ɝaʊn itʃ ə ðə hjumənz, kætʃpoʊlz ən hʊks fleɪlɪŋ. oʊnli læn ən ðə mɹdʒɹɑl dɪd ðeɪ əvɔɪd; ðoʊz tu fɔɾ ɪn ə klɪɹ sɝkəl, blæk hɔɹsəz mætʃɪŋ stɛp fəɹ stɛp, sɔɹdz mætʃɪŋ stʃɹoʊk fəɹ stʃɹoʊk. ði ɛɹ flæʃt ən pild.

Beast-muzzled almost-men swarmed around each of the humans, catchpoles and hooks flailing. Only Lan and the Myrddraal did they avoid; those two fought in a clear circle, black horses matching step for step, swords matching stroke for stroke. The air flashed and pealed.

klaʊd ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz ən skɹimd, ɹɪɹɪŋ ən læʃɪŋ aʊt wɪð ɪz hʊvz ət ðə snɑɹlɪŋ, ʃɑɹp-tuθ feɪsəz sɝaʊndɪŋ hɪm. hɛvi bɑɾiz kɹaʊɾəd ʃoʊldɝ-tə-ʃoʊldɝ ɝaʊn hɪm. dɪɡɪŋ ɪz hilz ɪn ɹuθləsli, ɹænd fɔɹs ðə ɡɹeɪ ɑn ɹəɡɑɹdləs, swɪŋɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd wɪð lɪɾəl ə ðə skɪl læn hæd tʃɹaɪd tə ɪmpɑɹt, hækɪŋ əz ɪf hjuɪŋ wʊd. ɛɡwin! dɛspɝətli hi sɝtʃt fəɹ əɹ əz i kɪk ðə ɡɹeɪ ɔnwɝd, slæʃɪŋ ə pæθ θɹu ðə hɛɹi bɑɾiz əz ðoʊ tʃɑpɪŋ ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ.

Cloud rolled his eyes and screamed, rearing and lashing out with his hooves at the snarling, sharp-toothed faces surrounding him. Heavy bodies crowded shoulder-to-shoulder around him. Digging his heels in ruthlessly, Rand forced the gray on regardless, swinging his sword with little of the skill Lan had tried to impart, hacking as if hewing wood. Egwene! Desperately he searched for her as he kicked the gray onward, slashing a path through the hairy bodies as though chopping undergrowth.

mɔɪɹeɪnz waɪt mɛɹ dæʃt ən kʌɾ ət ðə slaɪɾəst tʌtʃ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪz hæn ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz. hɝ feɪs wɑz əz hɑɹɾ əz lænz əz əɹ stæf læʃt aʊt. fleɪm ɛnvɛləp tʃɹɑləks, ðən bɝst wɪð ə ɹɔɹ ðət lɛf mɪsʃeɪpən fɔɹmz ənmoʊvɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin ɹoʊd kloʊs tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪð fɹæntɪk ɝdʒənsi, tiθ bɛɹɾ ɔlmoʊst əz fɪɹsli əz ðə tʃɹɑləks', bɛl naɪvz ɪn hænd. ðoʊz ʃɔɹt bleɪdz wəd bi noʊ jus əɾ ɔl ɪf ə tʃɹɑlɑk keɪm kloʊs. ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə tɝn klaʊd təwɔɹd ðɛm, bʌt ðə ɡɹeɪ hæd ðə bɪɾ ɪn ɪz tiθ. skɹimɪŋ ən kɪkɪŋ, klaʊd stʃɹʌɡəl fɔɹwɝd haʊɛvɝ hɑɹd ɹænd tʌɡd ət ðə ɹeɪnz.

Moiraine's white mare dashed and cut at the slightest touch of the Aes Sedai's hand on the reins. Her face was as hard as Lan's as her staff lashed out. Flame enveloped Trollocs, then burst with a roar that left misshapen forms unmoving on the ground. Nynaeve and Egwene rode close to the Aes Sedai with frantic urgency, teeth bared almost as fiercely as the Trollocs', belt knives in hand. Those short blades would be no use at all if a Trolloc came close. Rand tried to turn Cloud toward them, but the gray had the bit in his teeth. Screaming and kicking, Cloud struggled forward however hard Rand tugged at the reins.

ɝaʊn ðə θɹi wɪmən ə speɪs oʊpən əz tʃɹɑləks tʃɹaɪd tə fli fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪnz stæf, bʌɾ əz ðeɪ ətɛmptəd tə əvɔɪd hɝ, ʃi sɔɾ əm aʊt. faɪɝz ɹɔɹd, ən ðə tʃɹɑləks haʊld ɪn ɹeɪdʒ ən fjʊɹi. əbʌv ɹɔɹ ən haʊl kɹæʃt ðə toʊlɪŋ ə ðə wɔɹɾɝz sɔɹɾ əɡɛns ðə mɹdʒɹɑlz; ði ɛɹ flɛɹd blu ɝaʊn ðɛm, flɛɹɾ əɡɛn. əɡɛn.

Around the three women a space opened as Trollocs tried to flee from Moiraine's staff, but as they attempted to avoid her, she sought them out. Fires roared, and the Trollocs howled in rage and fury. Above roar and howl crashed the tolling of the Warder's sword against the Myrddraal's; the air flared blue around them, flared again. Again.

ə nus ɑn ði ɛn ʌv ə poʊl swɛpt ət ɹændz hɛd. wɪð ən ɑkwɝd slæʃ, hi kʌt ðə kætʃpoʊl ɪn tu, ðən hæk ðə ɡoʊt-feɪs tʃɹɑlɑk ðət hɛld ɪt. ə hʊk kɑɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ fɹəm bɪhaɪn ən tæŋɡəld ɪn ɪz kloʊk, dʒɝkɪŋ ɪm bækwɝdz. fɹæntəkəli, ɔlmoʊs luzɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd, hi klʌtʃt ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl tə kip ɪz sit. klaʊd twɪstəd, ʃɹikɪŋ. ɹænd hʌŋ ɑntu sæɾəl ən ɹeɪnz dɛspɝətli; hi kəd fil hɪmsɛlf slɪpɪŋ, ɪntʃ baɪ ɪntʃ, fɔlɪŋ tə ðə hʊk. klaʊd swʌŋ ɝaʊnd; fəɹ ən ɪnstən ɹænd sɔ pɛɹɪn, hæf aʊɾ ə hɪz sæɾəl, stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə ɹɛst ɪz æks əweɪ fɹəm θɹi tʃɹɑləks. ðeɪ hæɾ ɪm baɪ wʌn ɑɹm ən boʊθ lɛɡz. klaʊd plʌnʒd, ən oʊnli tʃɹɑləks fɪld ɹændz aɪz.

A noose on the end of a pole swept at Rand's head. With an awkward slash, he cut the catchpole in two, then hacked the goat-faced Trolloc that held it. A hook caught his shoulder from behind and tangled in his cloak, jerking him backwards. Frantically, almost losing his sword, he clutched the pommel of his saddle to keep his seat. Cloud twisted, shrieking. Rand hung onto saddle and reins desperately; he could feel himself slipping, inch by inch, falling to the hook. Cloud swung around; for an instant Rand saw Perrin, half out of his saddle, struggling to wrest his axe away from three Trollocs. They had him by one arm and both legs. Cloud plunged, and only Trollocs filled Rand's eyes.

eɪ tʃɹɑlɑk dæʃt ɪn ən sizd ɹændz lɛɡ, fɔɹsɪŋ ɪz fʊt fɹi ʌv ðə stɝəp. pæntɪŋ, hi lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv ðə sæɾəl tə stæb ɪt. ɪnstənli ðə hʊk pʊld ɪm aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl, tə klaʊdz haɪndkɔɹɾɝz; hɪz dɛθ-ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz wɑz ɔl ðət kɛpt ɪm fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd. klaʊd ɹɪɹɾ ən ʃɹikt. ən ɪn ðət seɪm moʊmən ðə pʊlɪŋ vænɪʃt. ðə tʃɹɑlɑk əɾ ɪz lɛɡ θɹu ʌp ɪts hænz ən skɹimd. ɔl ə ðə tʃɹɑləks skɹimd, ə haʊl laɪk ɔl ðə dɑɡz ɪn ðə wɝld ɡɔn mæd.

A Trolloc dashed in and seized Rand's leg, forcing his foot free of the stirrup. Panting, he let go of the saddle to stab it. Instantly the hook pulled him out of the saddle, to Cloud's hindquarters; his death-grip on the reins was all that kept him from the ground. Cloud reared and shrieked. And in that same moment the pulling vanished. The Trolloc at his leg threw up its hands and screamed. All of the Trollocs screamed, a howl like all the dogs in the world gone mad.

ɝaʊn ðə hjumənz tʃɹɑləks fɛl ɹaɪðɪŋ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, tɛɹɪŋ ət ðɛɹ hɛɹ, klɔɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn feɪsəz. ɔl ə ðə tʃɹɑləks. baɪɾɪŋ ət ðə ɡɹaʊnd, snæpɪŋ ət nʌθɪŋ, haʊlɪŋ, haʊlɪŋ, haʊlɪŋ.

Around the humans Trollocs fell writhing to the ground, tearing at their hair, clawing their own faces. All of the Trollocs. Biting at the ground, snapping at nothing, howling, howling, howling.

ðən ɹænd sɔ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl. stɪl əpɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəl ʌv ɪts mædli dænsɪŋ hɔɹs, blæk sɔɹd stɪl fleɪlɪŋ, ɪt hæd noʊ hɛd.

Then Rand saw the Myrddraal. Still upright in the saddle of its madly dancing horse, black sword still flailing, it had no head.

"ɪt woʊn daɪ əntɪl naɪtfɔl," tɑm hæd tə ʃaʊt, bɪtwin hɛvi bɹɛθs, oʊvɝ ði ʌnɹilɛntɪŋ skɹimz. "nɑt kəmplitli. ðəɾ ɪz wʌɾ aɪv hɝd, ɛniweɪ."

"It won't die until nightfall," Thom had to shout, between heavy breaths, over the unrelenting screams. "Not completely. That is what I've heard, anyway."

"ɹaɪd!" læn ʃaʊɾəd æŋɡɹəli. ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡæðɝd mɔɪɹeɪn ən ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən ən hæɾ əm hæfweɪ ʌp ðə nɛks hɪl. "ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ɔl ə ðɛm!" ɪndid, ðə hɔɹnz dɝdʒd əɡɛn, əbʌv ðə ʃɹiks ə ðə tʃɹɑləks ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, tə ist ən wɛst ən saʊθ.

"Ride!" Lan shouted angrily. The Warder had already gathered Moiraine and the other two women and had them halfway up the next hill. "This is not all of them!" Indeed, the horns dirged again, above the shrieks of the Trollocs on the ground, to east and west and south.

fəɹ ə wʌndɝ, mæt wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn u hæd bɪn ənhɔɹst. ɹænd tʃɹɑɾəd təwɔɹd hɪm, bʌt mæt tɔst ə nus əweɪ fɹəm ɪm wɪð ə ʃʌɾɝ, ɡæðɝɾ ɪz baʊ, ən skɹæmbəld ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl əneɪɾɪd, ðoʊ ɹʌbɪŋ əɾ ɪz θɹoʊt.

For a wonder, Mat was the only one who had been unhorsed. Rand trotted toward him, but Mat tossed a noose away from him with a shudder, gathered his bow, and scrambled into his saddle unaided, though rubbing at his throat.

ðə hɔɹnz beɪd laɪk haʊnz wɪð ðə sɛn ʌv ə dɪɹ. haʊnz kloʊzɪŋ ɪn. ɪf læn hæd sɛɾ ə hɑɹd peɪs bɪfɔɹ, hi dʌbəld ɪt naʊ, tɪl ðə hɔɹsəz skɹæbəld ʌphɪl fæstɝ ðən ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn daʊn bɪfɔɹ, ðən nɪɹli θɹu ðɛmsɛlvz ət ði ʌðɝ saɪd. bʌt stɪl ðə hɔɹnz keɪm ɛvɝ nɪɹɝ, əntɪl ðə ɡʌɾɝəl ʃaʊts ə pɝsut wɝ hɝd wɛnɛvɝ ðə hɔɹnz pɔzd, əntɪl ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðə hjumənz ɹitʃt ə hɪltɑp dʒʌst əz tʃɹɑləks əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðə nɛks hɪl bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ðə hɪltɑp blækənd wɪð tʃɹɑləks, snaʊɾəd, dɪstɔɹɾəd feɪsəz haʊlɪŋ, ən θɹi mɹdʒɹɑl oʊvɝɔɾ əm ɔl. oʊnli ə hʌnʒɹəd spænz sɛpɝeɪɾəd ðə tu pɑɹɾiz.

The horns bayed like hounds with the scent of a deer. Hounds closing in. If Lan had set a hard pace before, he doubled it now, till the horses scrabbled uphill faster than they had gone down before, then nearly threw themselves at the other side. But still the horns came ever nearer, until the guttural shouts of pursuit were heard whenever the horns paused, until eventually the humans reached a hilltop just as Trollocs appeared on the next hill behind them. The hilltop blackened with Trollocs, snouted, distorted faces howling, and three Myrddraal overawed them all. Only a hundred spans separated the two parties.

ɹændz hɑɹt ʃɹɪvəld laɪk ən oʊld ɡɹeɪp. θɹi!

Rand's heart shriveled like an old grape. Three!

ðə mɹdʒɹɑlz blæk sɔɹdz ɹoʊz əz wʌn; tʃɹɑləks bɔɪl daʊn ðə sloʊp, θɪk, tʃɹaɪʌmfən kɹaɪz ɹaɪzɪŋ, kætʃpoʊlz bɑbɪŋ əbʌv əz ðeɪ ɹæn.

The Myrddraal's black swords rose as one; Trollocs boiled down the slope, thick, triumphant cries rising, catchpoles bobbing above as they ran.

mɔɪɹeɪn klaɪm daʊn fɹəm ɑldibz bæk. kɑmli ʃi ɹimuv sʌmθɪŋ fɹəm əɹ paʊtʃ, ənɹæpt ɪt. ɹænd ɡlɪmps dɑɹk aɪvɝi. ði æŋɡɹil. wɪð æŋɡɹil ɪn wʌn hæn ən stæf ɪn ði ʌðɝ, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛɾ əɹ fit, feɪsɪŋ ði ɑnɹʌʃɪŋ tʃɹɑləks ən ðə feɪdz' blæk sɔɹdz, ɹeɪzd əɹ stæf haɪ, ən stæbd ɪt daʊn ɪndə ði ɝθ.

Moiraine climbed down from Aldieb's back. Calmly she removed something from her pouch, unwrapped it. Rand glimpsed dark ivory. The angreal. With angreal in one hand and staff in the other, the Aes Sedai set her feet, facing the onrushing Trollocs and the Fades' black swords, raised her staff high, and stabbed it down into the earth.

ðə ɡɹaʊn ɹæŋ laɪk ən aɪɝn kɛɾəl stʃɹʌk baɪ ə mælɪt. ðə hɑloʊ klæŋ dwɪndəld, feɪɾəd əweɪ. fəɹ ən ɪnstən ðɛn, ɪt wɑz saɪlənt. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz saɪlənt. ðə wɪn daɪd. ðə tʃɹɑlɑk kɹaɪz stɪld; ivən ðɛɹ tʃɑɹdʒ fɔɹwɝd sloʊɾ ən stɑpt. fəɹ ə hɑɹtbit, ɛvɹiθɪŋ weɪɾəd. sloʊli ðə dʌl ɹɪŋɪŋ ɹɪtɝnd, tʃeɪnʒɪŋ tə ə loʊ ɹʌmbəl, ɡɹoʊɪŋ əntɪl ði ɝθ moʊnd.

The ground rang like an iron kettle struck by a mallet. The hollow clang dwindled, faded away. For an instant then, it was silent. Everything was silent. The wind died. The Trolloc cries stilled; even their charge forward slowed and stopped. For a heartbeat, everything waited. Slowly the dull ringing returned, changing to a low rumble, growing until the earth moaned.

ðə ɡɹaʊn tʃɹɛmbəl bɪniθ klaʊdz hʊvz. ðɪs wɑz ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝk laɪk ðə stɔɹiz toʊld əbaʊt; ɹænd wɪʃt i wɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz əweɪ. ðə tʃɹɛmbəl bɪkeɪm ə ʃeɪkɪŋ ðət sɛt ðə tʃɹiz ɝaʊn əm kwɪvɝɪŋ. ðə ɡɹeɪ stʌmbəld ən nɪɹli fɛl. ivən mændɑɹb ən ɹaɪɾɝləs ɑldib stæɡɝɾ əz ɪf dʒɹʌŋk, ən ðoʊz u ɹoʊd hæd tə klɪŋ tə ɹeɪnz ən meɪnz, tə ɛniθɪŋ, tə kip ðɛɹ sits.

The ground trembled beneath Cloud's hooves. This was Aes Sedai work like the stories told about; Rand wished he were a hundred miles away. The tremble became a shaking that set the trees around them quivering. The gray stumbled and nearly fell. Even Mandarb and riderless Aldieb staggered as if drunk, and those who rode had to cling to reins and manes, to anything, to keep their seats.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stɪl stʊɾ əz ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn, hoʊldɪŋ ði æŋɡɹil ən əɹ əpɹaɪt stæf θɹʌst ɪndə ðə hɪltɑp, ən niðɝ ʃi nɔɹ ðə stæf muvd ən ɪntʃ, fəɹ ɔl ðət ðə ɡɹaʊnd ʃʊk ən ʃɪvɝɾ ɝaʊn hɝ. naʊ ðə ɡɹaʊn ɹɪpəld, spɹɪŋɪŋ aʊt fɹəm ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ stæf, læpɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹɑləks laɪk ɹɪpəlz ɑn ə pɑnd, ɹɪpəlz ðət ɡɹu əz ðeɪ ɹæn, tɑpəlɪŋ oʊl bʊʃəz, flɪŋɪŋ dɛd livz ɪndə ði ɛɹ, ɡɹoʊɪŋ, bɪkʌmɪŋ weɪvz ə ɝθ, ɹoʊlɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹɑləks. tʃɹiz ɪn ðə hɑloʊ læʃt laɪk swɪtʃəz ɪn ðə hænz ə smɔl bɔɪz. ɑn ðə fɑɹ sloʊp tʃɹɑləks fɛl ɪn hips, tʌmbəld oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ baɪ ðə ɹeɪdʒɪŋ ɝθ.

The Aes Sedai still stood as she had begun, holding the angreal and her upright staff thrust into the hilltop, and neither she nor the staff moved an inch, for all that the ground shook and shivered around her. Now the ground rippled, springing out from in front of her staff, lapping toward the Trollocs like ripples on a pond, ripples that grew as they ran, toppling old bushes, flinging dead leaves into the air, growing, becoming waves of earth, rolling toward the Trollocs. Trees in the hollow lashed like switches in the hands of small boys. On the far slope Trollocs fell in heaps, tumbled over and over by the raging earth.

jɛɾ əz ɪf ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɝ nɑt ɹɪɹɪŋ ɔl ɝaʊn ðɛm, ðə mɹdʒɹɑl muv fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ə laɪn, ðɛɹ dɛd-blæk hɔɹsəz nɛvɝ mɪsɪŋ ə stɛp, ɛvɹi huf ɪn junəsən. tʃɹɑləks ɹoʊld ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ɔl əbaʊt ðə blæk stidz, haʊlɪŋ ən ɡɹæbɪŋ ət ðə hɪlsaɪd ðət hivd əm ʌp, bʌt ðə mɹdʒɹɑl keɪm sloʊli ɑn.

Yet as if the ground were not rearing all around them, the Myrddraal moved forward in a line, their dead-black horses never missing a step, every hoof in unison. Trollocs rolled on the ground all about the black steeds, howling and grabbing at the hillside that heaved them up, but the Myrddraal came slowly on.

mɔɪɹeɪn lɪftəɾ əɹ stæf, ən ði ɝθ stɪld, bʌt ʃi wɑz nɑt dʌn. ʃi pɔɪntəd tə ðə hɑloʊ bɪtwin ðə hɪlz, ən fleɪm ɡtəd fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ə faʊntən twɛnti fit haɪ. ʃi flʌŋ əɹ ɑɹmz waɪd, ən ðə faɪɝ ɹeɪs tə lɛft ən ɹaɪɾ əz fɑɹ əz ði aɪ kəd si, spɹɛɾɪŋ ɪndə ə wɔl sɛpɝeɪɾɪŋ hjumənz ən tʃɹɑləks. ðə hit meɪd ɹænd pʊɾ ɪz hænz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz feɪs, ivən ɑn ðə hɪltɑp. ðə mɹdʒɹɑlz blæk maʊns, wʌtɛvɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ paʊɝz ðeɪ hæd, skɹimd ət ðə faɪɝ, ɹɪɹɾ ən fɔt ðɛɹ ɹaɪɾɝz əz ðə mɹdʒɹɑl biɾ ət ðɛm, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɔɹs əm θɹu ðə fleɪmz.

Moiraine lifted her staff, and the earth stilled, but she was not done. She pointed to the hollow between the hills, and flame gouted from the ground, a fountain twenty feet high. She flung her arms wide, and the fire raced to left and right as far as the eye could see, spreading into a wall separating humans and Trollocs. The heat made Rand put his hands in front of his face, even on the hilltop. The Myrddraal's black mounts, whatever strange powers they had, screamed at the fire, reared and fought their riders as the Myrddraal beat at them, trying to force them through the flames.

"blʌɾ ən æʃəz," mæt sɛd feɪnli. ɹænd nɑɾəd nʌmbli.

"Blood and ashes," Mat said faintly. Rand nodded numbly.

əbɹʌpli mɔɪɹeɪn weɪvɝɾ ən wʊɾə fɔlən hæd læn nɑt lɛp fɹəm ɪz hɔɹs tə kætʃ hɝ. "ɡoʊ ɑn," hi toʊl ði ʌðɝz. ðə hɑɹʃnəs ə hɪz vɔɪs wɑz əɾ ɑdz wɪð ðə dʒɛntəl weɪ hi lɪftəd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hɝ sæɾəl. "ðæt faɪɝ woʊn bɝn fɝɛvɝ. hɝi! ɛvɹi mɪnət kaʊns!"

Abruptly Moiraine wavered and would have fallen had Lan not leaped from his horse to catch her. "Go on," he told the others. The harshness of his voice was at odds with the gentle way he lifted the Aes Sedai to her saddle. "That fire won't burn forever. Hurry! Every minute counts!"

ðə wɔl ə fleɪm ɹɔɹɾ əz ɪf ɪt wəɾ ɪndid bɝn fɝɛvɝ, bʌt ɹænd dɪd nɑɾ ɑɹɡju. ðeɪ ɡæləp nɔɹθwɝɾ əz fæst əz ðeɪ kəd meɪk ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz ɡoʊ. ðə hɔɹnz ɪn ðə dɪstəns ʃɹɪld aʊt dɪsəpɔɪnmənt, əz ɪf ðeɪ ɔlɹɛɾi nu wʌt hæd hæpənd, ðən fɛl saɪlənt.

The wall of flame roared as if it would indeed burn forever, but Rand did not argue. They galloped northward as fast as they could make their horses go. The horns in the distance shrilled out disappointment, as if they already knew what had happened, then fell silent.

læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn sun kɑɾ ʌp wɪð ði ʌðɝz, ðoʊ læn lɛɾ ɑldib baɪ ðə ɹeɪnz waɪl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sweɪɾ ən hɛl ðə pɑməl ə hɝ sæɾəl wɪð boʊθ hænz. "aɪ wɪl bi ɔl ɹaɪt sun," ʃi sɛd tə ðɛɹ wɝid lʊks. ʃi saʊndəd taɪɝd jɛt kɑnfəɾənt, ən əɹ ɡeɪz wɑz əz kəmpɛlɪŋ əz ɛvɝ. "aɪ æm nɑɾ ət maɪ stʃɹɔŋɡəst wən wɝkɪŋ wɪð ɝθ ən faɪɝ. ə smɔl θɪŋ."

Lan and Moiraine soon caught up with the others, though Lan led Aldieb by the reins while the Aes Sedai swayed and held the pommel of her saddle with both hands. "I will be all right soon," she said to their worried looks. She sounded tired yet confident, and her gaze was as compelling as ever. "I am not at my strongest when working with Earth and Fire. A small thing."

ðə tu ʌv əm muvd ɪndə ðə lɛɾ əɡɛn əɾ ə fæst wɔk. ɹænd dɪd nɑt θɪŋk mɔɪɹeɪn kəd steɪ ɪn ðə sæɾəl əɾ ɛni fæstɝ peɪs. nɪneɪiv ɹoʊd faʊɹd bɪsaɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, stɛɾiɪŋ əɹ wɪð ə hænd. fəɹ ə taɪm əz ðə pɑɹɾi wɛn ɑn əkɹɔs ðə hɪlz ðə tu wɪmən wɪspɝd, ðən ðə wɪzdəm dɛlvd ɪndə hɝ kloʊk ən hændəɾ ə smɔl pækət tə mɔɪɹeɪn. mɔɪɹeɪn ənfoʊldəɾ ɪɾ ən swɑloʊd ðə kɑntɛns. nɪneɪiv sɛd sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ, ðən fɛl bæk wɪð ði ʌðɝz, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðɛɹ kwɛstʃənɪŋ lʊks. dɪspaɪt ðɛɹ sɝkəmstænsəz, ɹænd θɔt ʃi hæɾ ə slaɪt lʊk ə sæɾəsfækʃən.

The two of them moved into the lead again at a fast walk. Rand did not think Moiraine could stay in the saddle at any faster pace. Nynaeve rode foward beside the Aes Sedai, steadying her with a hand. For a time as the party went on across the hills the two women whispered, then the Wisdom delved into her cloak and handed a small packet to Moiraine. Moiraine unfolded it and swallowed the contents. Nynaeve said something more, then fell back with the others, ignoring their questioning looks. Despite their circumstances, Rand thought she had a slight look of satisfaction.

hi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli kɛɹ wʌt ðə wɪzdəm wɑz ʌp tə. hi ɹʌb ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd kəntɪnjuəli, ən wɛnɛvɝ i ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ, hi stɛɹd daʊn əɾ ɪɾ ɪn wʌndɝ. soʊ ðæts wʌɾ ə bæɾəl ɪz laɪk. hi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ mʌtʃ ʌv ɪt, nɑɾ ɛni pɝtɪkjəlɝ pɑɹt. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɹæn təɡɛðɝ ɪn ɪz hɛd, ə mɛltəd mæs ə hɛɹi feɪsəz ən fɪɹ. fɪɹ ən hit. ɪt hæd simd əz hɑɾ əz ə mɪdsʌmɝ nun waɪl ɪt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. hi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ðæt. ði aɪsi wɪnd wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɹiz bidz ə pɝspɝeɪʃən ɔl oʊvɝ ɪz feɪs ən bɑɾi.

He did not really care what the Wisdom was up to. He rubbed the hilt of his sword continually, and whenever he realized what he was doing, he stared down at it in wonder. So that's what a battle is like. He could not remember much of it, not any particular part. Everything ran together in his head, a melted mass of hairy faces and fear. Fear and heat. It had seemed as hot as a midsummer noon while it was going on. He could not understand that. The icy wind was trying to freeze beads of perspiration all over his face and body.

hi ɡlænst əɾ ɪz tu fɹɛnz. mæt wɑz skɹʌbɪŋ swɛɾ ɔf ɪz feɪs wɪð ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz kloʊk. pɛɹɪn, stɛɹɪŋ ət sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə dɪstəns ən nɑt laɪkɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑz siɪŋ, əpɪɹɾ ʌnəwɛɹ ə ðə bidz ɡlɪsnɪŋ ɑn ɪz fɔɹhɛd.

He glanced at his two friends. Mat was scrubbing sweat off his face with the edge of his cloak. Perrin, staring at something in the distance and not liking what he was seeing, appeared unaware of the beads glistening on his forehead.

ðə hɪlz ɡɹu smɔlɝ, ən ðə læn bɪɡæn tə lɛvəl aʊt, bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə pɹɛsɪŋ ɑn, læn stɑpt. nɪneɪiv muvd əz ɪf tə ɹidʒɔɪn mɔɪɹeɪn, bʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝz lʊk kɛpt əɹ əweɪ. hi ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹoʊɾ əhɛɾ ən pʊt ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ, ən fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪnz dʒɛstʃɝz ɪt bɪkeɪm əpɛɹən ðeɪ wɝ ɑɹɡjuɪŋ. nɪneɪiv ən tɑm stɛɹɾ ət ðɛm, ðə wɪzdəm fɹaʊnɪŋ wɝidli, ðə ɡlimən mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ ən pɔzɪŋ tə stɛɹ bæk ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd kʌm, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ əɾ əm ɔltəɡɛðɝ. hu nu wʌt maɪt kʌm aʊɾ ʌv ən ɑɹɡjəmən bɪtwin ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ə wɔɹɾɝ?

The hills grew smaller, and the land began to level out, but instead of pressing on, Lan stopped. Nynaeve moved as if to rejoin Moiraine, but the Warder's look kept her away. He and the Aes Sedai rode ahead and put their heads together, and from Moiraine's gestures it became apparent they were arguing. Nynaeve and Thom stared at them, the Wisdom frowning worriedly, the gleeman muttering under his breath and pausing to stare back the way they had come, but everyone else avoided looking at them altogether. Who knew what might come out of an argument between an Aes Sedai and a Warder?

æftɝ ə fju mɪnəts ɛɡwin spoʊk tə ɹænd kwaɪətli, kæstɪŋ ən ənizi aɪ ət ðə stɪl-ɑɹɡjuɪŋ pɛɹ. "ðoʊz θɪŋz jə wɝ ʃaʊɾɪŋ ət ðə tʃɹɑləks." ʃi stɑpt əz ɪf ənʃʊɹ haʊ tə pɹəsid.

After a few minutes Egwene spoke to Rand quietly, casting an uneasy eye at the still-arguing pair. "Those things you were shouting at the Trollocs." She stopped as if unsure how to proceed.

"wʌɾ əbaʊt ðɛm?" ɹænd æskt. hi fɛlt ə lɪɾəl ɑkwɝd - wɔɹkɹaɪz wɝ ɔl ɹaɪt fəɹ wɔɹɾɝz; tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk dɪd nɑt də θɪŋz laɪk ðæt, wʌtɛvɝ mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd - bʌɾ ɪf ʃi meɪd fʌn ə hɪm oʊvɝ ɪt. . . . "mæt mʌst əv ɹɪpiɾɪd ðət stɔɹi tɛn taɪmz."

"What about them?" Rand asked. He felt a little awkward - warcries were all right for Warders; Two Rivers folk did not do things like that, whatever Moiraine said - but if she made fun of him over it. . . . "Mat must have repeated that story ten times."

"æn bædli," tɑm pʊɾ ɪn. mæt ɡɹʌntɪɾ ɪn pɹoʊɾɛst.

"And badly," Thom put in. Mat grunted in protest.

"haʊɛvɝ i toʊld ɪt," ɹænd sɛd, "wiv ɔl hɝɾ ɪɾ ɛni nʌmbɝ ə taɪmz. bɪsaɪdz, wi hæd tə ʃaʊt sʌmθɪŋ. aɪ min, ðæts wʌt jə də əɾ ə taɪm laɪk ðæt. jə hɝd læn."

"However he told it," Rand said, "we've all heard it any number of times. Besides, we had to shout something. I mean, that's what you do at a time like that. You heard Lan."

"ænd wɪv ə ɹaɪt," pɛɹɪn æɾəd θɔtfəli. "mɔɪɹeɪn sɛz wɝ ɔl dɪsɛndəd fɹəm ðoʊz meɪnɛðɝən pipəl. ðeɪ fɔt ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ən wɝ faɪɾɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ðət ɡɪvz əs ə ɹaɪt."

"And we have a right," Perrin added thoughtfully. "Moiraine says we're all descended from those Manetheren people. They fought the Dark One, and we're fighting the Dark One. That gives us a right."

ɛɡwin snɪft əz ɪf tə ʃoʊ wʌt ʃi θɔɾ ə ðæt. "aɪ wɑzn tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðæt. wʌt . . . wʌt wɑz ɪt jə wɝ ʃaʊɾɪŋ, mæt?"

Egwene sniffed as if to show what she thought of that. "I wasn't talking about that. What . . . what was it you were shouting, Mat?"

mæt ʃɹʌɡd ənkʌmftəbli. "aɪ doʊn ɹɪmɛmbɝ." hi stɛɹɾ əɾ əm dɪfɛnsɪvli. "wɛl, aɪ doʊnt. ɪts ɔl fɑɡi. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz, əɹ wɛɹ ɪt keɪm fɹʌm, əɹ wʌɾ ɪt minz." hi ɡeɪv ə sɛlf-dɛpɹəkeɪɾɪŋ læf. "aɪ doʊn səpoʊz ɪt minz ɛniθɪŋ."

Mat shrugged uncomfortably. "I don't remember." He stared at them defensively. "Well, I don't. It's all foggy. I don't know what it was, or where it came from, or what it means." He gave a self-deprecating laugh. "I don't suppose it means anything."

"aɪ . . . aɪ θɪŋk ɪt dʌz," ɛɡwin sɛd sloʊli. "wɛn jə ʃaʊɾəd, aɪ θɔt - dʒʌs fəɹ ə mɪnət - aɪ θɔɾ aɪ ʌndɝstʊd ju. bʌɾ ɪts ɔl ɡɔn, naʊ." ʃi saɪɾ ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "pɝhæps jəɹ ɹaɪt. stʃɹeɪnʒ wʌt jə kən ɪmædʒən əɾ ə taɪm laɪk ðæt, ɪzən ɪt?"

"I . . . I think it does," Egwene said slowly. "When you shouted, I thought - just for a minute - I thought I understood you. But it's all gone, now." She sighed and shook her head. "Perhaps you're right. Strange what you can imagine at a time like that, isn't it?"

"kæɹɑi ən kɑldəzɑɹ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. ðeɪ ɔl twɪstəd tə stɛɹ ət hɝ. "kæɹɑi ən ɛlɪsɑnd. æl ɛlɪsɑnd. fəɹ ði ɑnɝ ə ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl. fəɹ ði ɑnɝ ə ðə ɹoʊz ə ðə sʌn. ðə ɹoʊz ə ðə sʌn. ði eɪntʃənt wɔɹkɹi ʌv meɪnɛðɝən, ən ðə wɔɹkɹi ʌv ɪts læs kɪŋ. ɛldʒɹin wɑz kɔl ðə ɹoʊz ə ðə sʌn." mɔɪɹeɪnz smaɪl tʊk ɪn ɛɡwin ən mæt boʊθ, ðoʊ hɝ ɡeɪz meɪ hæv ɹɛstəɾ ə moʊmən lɔŋɡɝ ɑn ɪm ðən ɑn hɝ. "ðə blʌɾ ʌv æɛmənz laɪn ɪz stɪl stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ði oʊl blʌd stɪl sɪŋz."

"Carai an Caldazar," Moiraine said. They all twisted to stare at her. "Carai an Ellisande. Al Ellisande. For the honor of the Red Eagle. For the honor of the Rose of the Sun. The Rose of the Sun. The ancient warcry of Manetheren, and the warcry of its last king. Eldrene was called the Rose of the Sun." Moiraine's smile took in Egwene and Mat both, though her gaze may have rested a moment longer on him than on her. "The blood of Aemon's line is still strong in the Two Rivers. The old blood still sings."

mæt ən ɛɡwin lʊkt əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ, waɪl ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls lʊkt əɾ əm boʊθ. ɛɡwinz aɪz wɝ waɪd, ən əɹ maʊθ kɛp kwɝkɪŋ ɪndə ə smaɪl ðət ʃi bɪt bæk ɛvɹi taɪm ɪt bɪɡæn, əz ɪf ʃi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ dʒʌs haʊ tə teɪk ðɪs tɔk ə ði oʊl blʌd. mæt wɑz ʃʊɹ, fɹəm ðə skaʊlɪŋ fɹaʊn ɑn ɪz feɪs.

Mat and Egwene looked at each other, while everyone else looked at them both. Egwene's eyes were wide, and her mouth kept quirking into a smile that she bit back every time it began, as if she was not sure just how to take this talk of the old blood. Mat was sure, from the scowling frown on his face.

ɹænd θɔɾ i nu wʌt mæt wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ. ðə seɪm θɪŋ i wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ. ɪf mæt wɑz ə dɪsɛndən ə ði eɪntʃən kɪŋz ə meɪnɛðɝən, meɪbi ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ ɹɪli æftɝ ɪm ən nɑɾ ɔl θɹi ʌv ðɛm. ðə θɔt meɪɾ ɪm əʃeɪmd. hɪz tʃiks kʌlɝd, ən wən i kɑɾ ə ɡɪlti ɡɹɪmɑs ɑn pɛɹɪnz feɪs, hi nu pɛɹɪn hæd bɪn hævɪŋ ðə seɪm θɔt.

Rand thought he knew what Mat was thinking. The same thing he was thinking. If Mat was a descendant of the ancient kings of Manetheren, maybe the Trollocs were really after him and not all three of them. The thought made him ashamed. His cheeks colored, and when he caught a guilty grimace on Perrin's face, he knew Perrin had been having the same thought.

"aɪ kæn seɪ ðəɾ aɪ hæv ɛvɝ hɝd ðə laɪk ə ðɪs," tɑm sɛɾ æftɝ ə mɪnət. hi ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf ən bɪkeɪm bɹʌsk. "ənʌðɝ taɪm aɪ maɪɾ ivən meɪk ə stɔɹi aʊɾ ʌv ɪt, bʌt ɹaɪt naʊ. . . . dʒju ɪntɛn tə ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə deɪ, ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

"I can't say that I have ever heard the like of this," Thom said after a minute. He shook himself and became brusque. "Another time I might even make a story out of it, but right now. . . . Do you intend to remain here for the rest of the day, Aes Sedai?"

"noʊ," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd, ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz.

"No," Moiraine replied, gathering her reins.

eɪ tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹn kin fɹəm ðə saʊθ əz ɪf tə ɛmfəsaɪz əɹ wɝd. mɔɹ hɔɹnz ænsɝd, ist ən wɛst. ðə hɔɹsəz wɪkɝɾ ən saɪɾəld əbaʊt nɝvəsli.

A Trolloc horn keened from the south as if to emphasize her word. More horns answered, east and west. The horses whickered and sidled about nervously.

"ðeɪ hæv pæs ðə faɪɝ," læn sɛd kɑmli. hi tɝn tə mɔɪɹeɪn. "ju ɑɹ nɑt stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ wʌt jə ɪntɛnd, nɑt jɛt, nɑt wɪθaʊt ɹɛst. ən niðɝ mɹdʒɹɑl nɔɹ tʃɹɑlɑk wɪl ɛntɝ ðət pleɪs."

"They have passed the fire," Lan said calmly. He turned to Moiraine. "You are not strong enough for what you intend, not yet, not without rest. And neither Myrddraal nor Trolloc will enter that place."

mɔɪɹeɪn ɹeɪzd ə hæn əz ɪf tə kʌɾ ɪm ɔf, ðən saɪɾ ən lɛɾ ɪt fɔl ɪnstɛd. "vɛɹi wɛl," ʃi sɛɾ ɪɹɪɾəbli. "ju ɑɹ ɹaɪt, aɪ səpoʊz, bʌɾ aɪ wəd ɹæðɝ ðəɹ wɑz ɛni ʌðɝ tʃɔɪs." ʃi pʊld əɹ stæf fɹəm ʌndɝ ðə ɡɝθ stʃɹæp ə hɝ sæɾəl. "ɡæðɝ ɪn ɝaʊn mi, ɔl ə ju. əz kloʊs əz jə kæn. kloʊsɝ."

Moiraine raised a hand as if to cut him off, then sighed and let it fall instead. "Very well," she said irritably. "You are right, I suppose, but I would rather there was any other choice." She pulled her staff from under the girth strap of her saddle. "Gather in around me, all of you. As close as you can. Closer."

ɹænd ɝdʒ klaʊd nɪɹɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz mɛɹ. ət mɔɪɹeɪnz ɪnsɪstəns ðeɪ kɛpt ɑn kɹaʊɾɪŋ kloʊsɝ ɪn ə sɝkəl ɝaʊn əɹ əntɪl ɛvɹi hɔɹs hæɾ ɪts hɛd stʃɹɛtʃt oʊvɝ ðə kɹup əɹ wɪðɝz ʌv ənʌðɝ. oʊnli ðən wɑz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sæɾəsfaɪd. ðɛn, wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ, ʃi stʊɾ ɪn ðə stɝəps ən swʌŋ əɹ stæf oʊvɝ ðɛɹ hɛdz, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ tə meɪk sɝɾən ɪt kʌvɝɾ ɛvɹiwʌn.

Rand urged Cloud nearer the Aes Sedai's mare. At Moiraine's insistence they kept on crowding closer in a circle around her until every horse had its head stretched over the croup or withers of another. Only then was the Aes Sedai satisfied. Then, without speaking, she stood in the stirrups and swung her staff over their heads, stretching to make certain it covered everyone.

ɹænd flɪntʃt itʃ taɪm ðə stæf pæst oʊvɝ hɪm. ə tɪŋɡəl ɹæn θɹu hɪm wɪð ɛvɹi pæs. hi cʊɾə fɑloʊd ðə stæf wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ɪt, dʒʌs baɪ fɑloʊɪŋ ðə ʃɪvɝz əz ɪt muvd oʊvɝ pipəl. ɪt wɑz noʊ sɝpɹaɪz tə hɪm ðət læn wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn nɑɾ əfɛktəd.

Rand flinched each time the staff passed over him. A tingle ran through him with every pass. He could have followed the staff without seeing it, just by following the shivers as it moved over people. It was no surprise to him that Lan was the only one not affected.

əbɹʌpli mɔɪɹeɪn θɹʌs ðə stæf aʊt tə ðə wɛst. dɛd livz wɝld ɪndə ði ɛɹ ən bɹæntʃəz wɪpt əz ɪf ə dʌst-dɛvəl ɹæn əlɔŋ ðə laɪn ʃi pɔɪntəd tə. əz ði ɪnvɪzəbəl wɝlwɪn vænɪʃt fɹəm saɪt ʃi sɛɾəld bæk ɪndə hɝ sæɾəl wɪð ə saɪ.

Abruptly Moiraine thrust the staff out to the west. Dead leaves whirled into the air and branches whipped as if a dust-devil ran along the line she pointed to. As the invisible whirlwind vanished from sight she settled back into her saddle with a sigh.

"tə ðə tʃɹɑləks," ʃi sɛd, "aʊɝ sɛns ən əɹ tʃɹæks wɪl sim tə fɑloʊ ðæt. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl wɪl si θɹu ɪɾ ɪn taɪm, bʌt baɪ ðɛn. . . ."

"To the Trollocs," she said, "our scents and our tracks will seem to follow that. The Myrddraal will see through it in time, but by then. . . ."

"baɪ ðɛn," læn sɛd, "wi wɪl əv lɔst aʊɝsɛlvz."

"By then," Lan said, "we will have lost ourselves."

"jɔɹ stæf ɪz vɛɹi paʊɝfəl," ɛɡwin sɛd, ɝnɪŋ ə snɪf fɹəm nɪneɪiv.

"Your staff is very powerful," Egwene said, earning a sniff from Nynaeve.

mɔɪɹeɪn meɪɾ ə klɪkɪŋ saʊnd. "aɪ hæv toʊl ju, tʃaɪld, θɪŋz də nɑɾ əv paʊɝ. ðə wʌn paʊɝ kʌmz fɹəm ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, ən oʊnli ə lɪvɪŋ maɪn kən wild ɪt. ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ivən ən æŋɡɹil, mɪɹli ən eɪd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪʃən." wɛɹəli ʃi slɪd ðə stæf bæk ʌndɝ əɹ ɡɝθ stʃɹæp. "læn?"

Moiraine made a clicking sound. "I have told you, child, things do not have power. The One Power comes from the True Source, and only a living mind can wield it. This is not even an angreal, merely an aid to concentration." Wearily she slid the staff back under her girth strap. "Lan?"

"fɑloʊ mi," ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd, "æn kip kwaɪət. ɪɾəl ɹuən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪf ðə tʃɹɑləks hɪɹ ʌs."

"Follow me," the Warder said, "and keep quiet. It will ruin everything if the Trollocs hear us."

hi lɛd ðə weɪ nɔɹθ əɡɛn, nɑɾ ət ðə kɹæʃɪŋ peɪs ðeɪ hæd bɪn meɪkɪŋ, bʌt ɹæðɝ ɪn ðə kwɪk wɔk wɪð wɪtʃ ðeɪ hæd tʃɹævəl ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd. ðə læn kəntɪnjud tə flæɾən, ðoʊ ðə fɔɹəst ɹɪmeɪn əz θɪk.

He led the way north again, not at the crashing pace they had been making, but rather in the quick walk with which they had traveled the Caemlyn Road. The land continued to flatten, though the forest remained as thick.

ðɛɹ pæθ wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ stʃɹeɪt, əz ɪt hæd bɪn bɪfɔɹ, fəɹ læn tʃoʊz aʊɾ ə ɹut ðət miændɝɾ oʊvɝ hɑɹd ɡɹaʊn ən ɹɑki aʊtkɹɑps, ən i noʊ lɔŋɡɝ lɛɾ əm fɔɹs ðɛɹ weɪ θɹu tæŋɡəlz ə bɹʌʃ, ɪnstɛd teɪkɪŋ ðə taɪm tə meɪk ðɛɹ weɪ ɝaʊnd. naʊ ən əɡɛn i dʒɹɑp tə ðə ɹɪɹ, ɪntɛnli stʌɾiɪŋ ðə tʃɹeɪl ðeɪ meɪd. ɪf ɛniwʌn soʊ mʌtʃ əz kɔft, ɪt dʒɹu ə ʃɑɹp ɡɹʌn fɹəm hɪm.

Their path was no longer straight, as it had been before, for Lan chose out a route that meandered over hard ground and rocky outcrops, and he no longer let them force their way through tangles of brush, instead taking the time to make their way around. Now and again he dropped to the rear, intently studying the trail they made. If anyone so much as coughed, it drew a sharp grunt from him.

nɪneɪiv ɹoʊd bɪsaɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, kənsɝn bæɾəlɪŋ dɪslaɪk ɑn əɹ feɪs. ən ðəɹ wɑz ə hɪn ə sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ, ɹænd θɔt, ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ðə wɪzdəm sɔ səm ɡoʊl ɪn saɪt. mɔɪɹeɪnz ʃoʊldɝz wɝ slʌmpt, ən ʃi hɛld əɹ ɹeɪnz ən ðə sæɾəl wɪð boʊθ hænz, sweɪɪŋ wɪð ɛvɹi stɛp ɑldib tʊk. ɪt wɑz pleɪn ðət leɪɪŋ ðə fɔls tʃɹeɪl, smɔl əz ðət maɪɾ əv sim bɪsaɪd pɹədusɪŋ ən ɝθkweɪk ən ə wɔl ə fleɪm, hæd teɪkən ə ɡɹeɪt dil aʊɾ ə hɝ, stʃɹɛŋkθ ʃi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hæd tə luz.

Nynaeve rode beside the Aes Sedai, concern battling dislike on her face. And there was a hint of something more, Rand thought, almost as if the Wisdom saw some goal in sight. Moiraine's shoulders were slumped, and she held her reins and the saddle with both hands, swaying with every step Aldieb took. It was plain that laying the false trail, small as that might have seemed beside producing an earthquake and a wall of flame, had taken a great deal out of her, strength she no longer had to lose.

ɹænd ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt ðə hɔɹnz wəd stɑɹɾ əɡɛn. ət lis ðeɪ wɝ ə weɪ ʌv tɛlɪŋ haʊ fɑɹ bæk ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ. ən ðə feɪdz.

Rand almost wished the horns would start again. At least they were a way of telling how far back the Trollocs were. And the Fades.

hi kɛp lʊkɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ən soʊ wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs tə si wʌt leɪ əhɛd. wən i dɪd, hi stɛɹd, pɝplɛkst. ə ɡɹeɪt, ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ mæs stʃɹɛtʃt ɔf tə iðɝ saɪɾ aʊɾ ə saɪt, ɪn moʊs pleɪsəz əz haɪ əz ðə tʃɹiz ðət ɡɹu ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ɪt, wɪð ivən tɔlɝ spaɪɹz hɪɹ ən ðɛɹ. lifləs vaɪnz ən kɹipɝz kʌvɝɾ ɪɾ ɔl ɪn θɪk leɪɝz. ə klɪf? ðə vaɪnz wɪl meɪk klaɪmɪŋ izi, bʌt wɪl nɛvɝ ɡɛt ðə hɔɹsəz ʌp.

He kept looking behind them, and so was not the first to see what lay ahead. When he did, he stared, perplexed. A great, irregular mass stretched off to either side out of sight, in most places as high as the trees that grew right up to it, with even taller spires here and there. Leafless vines and creepers covered it all in thick layers. A cliff? The vines will make climbing easy, but we'll never get the horses up.

sʌɾənli, əz ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ə lɪɾəl kloʊsɝ, hi sɔ ə taʊɝ. ɪt wɑz klɪɹli ə taʊɝ, nɑt səm kaɪndə ɹɑk fɔɹmeɪʃən, wɪð ən ɑd, pɔɪntəd doʊm ɑn ðə tɑp. "ə sɪɾi!" hi sɛd. ən ə sɪɾi wɔl, ən ðə spaɪɹz wɝ ɡɑɹd taʊɝz ɑn ðə wɔl. hɪz dʒɔ dʒɹɑpt. ɪt hæd tə bi tɛn taɪmz əz bɪɡ əz bɛɹlən. fɪfti taɪmz əz bɪɡ.

Suddenly, as they rode a little closer, he saw a tower. It was clearly a tower, not some kind of rock formation, with an odd, pointed dome on the top. "A city!" he said. And a city wall, and the spires were guard towers on the wall. His jaw dropped. It had to be ten times as big as Baerlon. Fifty times as big.

mæt nɑɾəd. "ə sɪɾi," hi əɡɹid. "bʌt wʌts ə sɪɾi duɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə fɔɹəs laɪk ðɪs?"

Mat nodded. "A city," he agreed. "But what's a city doing in the middle of a forest like this?"

"ænd wɪθaʊɾ ɛni pipəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. wən ðeɪ lʊkt ət hɪm, hi pɔɪntəd tə ðə wɔl. "wʊd pipəl lɛt vaɪnz ɡɹoʊ oʊvɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ laɪk ðæt? jə noʊ haʊ kɹipɝz kən tɛɹ daʊn ə wɔl. lʊk haʊ ɪts fɔlən."

"And without any people," Perrin said. When they looked at him, he pointed to the wall. "Would people let vines grow over everything like that? You know how creepers can tear down a wall. Look how it's fallen."

wʌt ɹænd sɔ ədʒʌstəɾ ɪtsɛlf ɪn ɪz maɪn əɡɛn. ɪt wɑz əz pɛɹɪn sɛd. ʌndɝ ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi loʊ pleɪs ɪn ðə wɔl wɑz ə bɹʌʃ-kʌvɝd hɪl; ɹʌbəl fɹəm ðə kəlæpst wɔl əbʌv. noʊ tu ʌv ðə ɡɑɹd taʊɝz wɝ ðə seɪm haɪt.

What Rand saw adjusted itself in his mind again. It was as Perrin said. Under almost every low place in the wall was a brush-covered hill; rubble from the collapsed wall above. No two of the guard towers were the same height.

"aɪ wʌndɝ wʌt sɪɾi ɪt wɑz," ɛɡwin mjuzd. "aɪ wʌndɝ wʌt hæpən tə ɪt. aɪ doʊn ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛniθɪŋ fɹəm pɑpəz mæp."

"I wonder what city it was," Egwene mused. "I wonder what happened to it. I don't remember anything from papa's map."

"ɪt wɑz kɔld ɑɹɪdhɔl," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ɪn ðə deɪz ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, ɪt wɑz ən ælaɪ ʌv meɪnɛðɝən." stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə mæsɪv wɔlz, ʃi simd ɔlmoʊst ʌnəwɛɹ ə ði ʌðɝz, ivən ə nɪneɪiv, hu səpɔɹɾəd əɹ ɪn ðə sæɾəl wɪð ə hæn ɑn əɹ ɑɹm. "leɪɾɝ ɑɹɪdhɔl daɪd, ən ðɪs pleɪs wɑz kɔl baɪ ənʌðɝ neɪm."

"It was called Aridhol," Moiraine said. "In the days of the Trolloc Wars, it was an ally of Manetheren." Staring at the massive walls, she seemed almost unaware of the others, even of Nynaeve, who supported her in the saddle with a hand on her arm. "Later Aridhol died, and this place was called by another name."

"wʌt neɪm?" mæt æskt.

"What name?" Mat asked.

"hɪɹ," læn sɛd. hi stɑp mændɑɹb ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wʌt hæd wʌns bɪn ə ɡeɪt waɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ fɪfti mɛn tə mɑɹtʃ θɹu əbɹɛst. oʊnli ðə bɹoʊkən, vaɪn-ɛnkɹʌstɪd wɑtʃtaʊɝz ɹɪmeɪnd; ʌv ðə ɡeɪts ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn. "wi ɛntɝ hɪɹ." tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹnz ʃɹikt ɪn ðə dɪstəns. læn pɪɹɾ ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðə saʊnd, ðən lʊkt ət ðə sʌn, hæfweɪ daʊn təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹitɑps ɪn ðə wɛst. "ðeɪ hæv dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪts ə fɔls tʃɹeɪl. kʌm, wi mʌs faɪnd ʃɛltɝ bɪfɔɹ dɑɹk."

"Here," Lan said. He stopped Mandarb in front of what had once been a gate wide enough for fifty men to march through abreast. Only the broken, vine-encrusted watchtowers remained; of the gates there was no sign. "We enter here." Trolloc horns shrieked in the distance. Lan peered in the direction of the sound, then looked at the sun, halfway down toward the treetops in the west. "They have discovered it's a false trail. Come, we must find shelter before dark."

"wʌt neɪm?" mæt æskt əɡɛn.

"What name?" Mat asked again.

mɔɪɹeɪn ænsɝɾ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi. "ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ," ʃi sɛd. "ɪɾ ɪz kɔld ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ."

Moiraine answered as they rode into the city. "Shadar Logoth," she said. "It is called Shadar Logoth."


tʃæptɝ naɪntin


CHAPTER 19

ʃædoʊz weɪɾɪŋ


Shadow's Waiting

bɹoʊkən peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz kɹʌntʃt ʌndɝ ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz əz læn lɛd ðə weɪ ɪndə ðə sɪɾi. ði ɪntaɪɝ sɪɾi wɑz bɹoʊkən, wʌt ɹænd kəd si ʌv ɪt, ən əz əbændən əz pɛɹɪn hæd sɛd. nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə pɪdʒən muvd, ən widz, meɪnli oʊld ən dɛd, spɹaʊɾəd fɹəm kɹæks ɪn wɔlz əz wɛl əz peɪvmənt. mɔɹ bɪldɪŋz hæd ɹufs fɔlən ɪn ðən hæɾ əm hoʊl. tʌmbəld wɔlz spɪl fænz ə bɹɪk ən stoʊn ɪndə ðə stʃɹits. taʊɝz stɑpt, əbɹʌpt ən dʒæɡd, laɪk bɹoʊkən stɪks. ənivən ɹʌbəl hɪlz wɪð ə fju stʌntɪd tʃɹiz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ sloʊps cʊɾə bɪn ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ə pæləsəz əɹ ʌv ɪntaɪɝ blɑks ə ðə sɪɾi.

Broken paving stones crunched under the horses' hooves as Lan led the way into the city. The entire city was broken, what Rand could see of it, and as abandoned as Perrin had said. Not so much as a pigeon moved, and weeds, mainly old and dead, sprouted from cracks in walls as well as pavement. More buildings had roofs fallen in than had them whole. Tumbled walls spilled fans of brick and stone into the streets. Towers stopped, abrupt and jagged, like broken sticks. Uneven rubble hills with a few stunted trees growing on their slopes could have been the remains of palaces or of entire blocks of the city.

jɛt wʌt wɑz lɛf stændɪŋ wɑz ɪnʌf tə teɪk ɹændz bɹɛθ. ðə lɑɹdʒəs bɪldɪŋ ɪn bɛɹlən wʊɾə vænɪʃt ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz ʌv ɔlmoʊst ɛniθɪŋ hɪɹ. peɪl mɑɹbəl pæləsəz tɑpt wɪð hjudʒ doʊmz mɛɾ ɪm wɛɹɛvɝ i lʊkt. ɛvɹi bɪldɪŋ əpɪɹd tə hæv ət list wʌn doʊm; səm hæd fɔɹ əɹ faɪv, ən itʃ wʌn ʃeɪp dɪfɹənli. lɔŋ wɔks laɪn baɪ kɑləmz ɹæn hʌnʒɹədz ə peɪsɪz tə taʊɝz ðət sim tə ɹitʃ ðə skaɪ. əɾ ɛvɹi ɪntɝsɛkʃən stʊɾ ə bɹɑnz faʊntən, əɹ ði æləbæstɝ spaɪɹ ʌv ə mɑnjəmənt, əɹ ə stætʃu ɑn ə pɛɾəstəl. ɪf ðə faʊntənz wɝ dʒɹaɪ, moʊst ə ðə spaɪɹz tɑpəld, ən mɛni ʌv ðə stætʃuz bɹoʊkən, wʌt ɹɪmeɪnd wɑz soʊ ɡɹeɪt ðəɾ i kəɾ oʊnli mɑɹvəl.

Yet what was left standing was enough to take Rand's breath. The largest building in Baerlon would have vanished in the shadows of almost anything here. Pale marble palaces topped with huge domes met him wherever he looked. Every building appeared to have at least one dome; some had four or five, and each one shaped differently. Long walks lined by columns ran hundreds of paces to towers that seemed to reach the sky. At every intersection stood a bronze fountain, or the alabaster spire of a monument, or a statue on a pedestal. If the fountains were dry, most of the spires toppled, and many of the statues broken, what remained was so great that he could only marvel.

ən aɪ θɔt bɛɹlən wɑz ə sɪɾi! bɝn mi, bʌt tɑm mʌst əv bɪn læfɪŋ ʌp ɪz sliv. mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn, tu.

And I thought Baerlon was a city! Burn me, but Thom must have been laughing up his sleeve. Moiraine and Lan, too.

hi wɑz soʊ kɑɾ ʌp ɪn stɛɹɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz teɪkən baɪ sɝpɹaɪz wən læn sʌɾənli stɑpt ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ə waɪt stoʊn bɪldɪŋ ðət hæd wʌns bɪn twaɪs əz bɪɡ əz ðə stæɡ ən laɪən ɪn bɛɹlən. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə seɪ wʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn wən ðə sɪɾi lɪvd ən wɑz ɡɹeɪt, pɝhæps ivən ən ɪn. oʊnli ə hɑloʊ ʃɛl ɹɪmeɪn ə ði ʌpɝ flɔɹz - ði æftɝnun skaɪ wɑz vɪzəbəl θɹu ɛmpti wɪndoʊ fɹeɪmz, ɡlæs ən wʊɾ əlaɪk lɔŋ sɪns ɡɔn - bʌt ðə ɡɹaʊn flɔɹ sim saʊn ɪnʌf.

He was so caught up in staring that he was taken by surprise when Lan suddenly stopped in front of a white stone building that had once been twice as big as the Stag and Lion in Baerlon. There was nothing to say what it had been when the city lived and was great, perhaps even an inn. Only a hollow shell remained of the upper floors - the afternoon sky was visible through empty window frames, glass and wood alike long since gone - but the ground floor seemed sound enough.

mɔɪɹeɪn, hænz stɪl ɑn ðə pɑməl, stʌɾid ðə bɪldɪŋ ɪntɛnli bɪfɔɹ nɑɾɪŋ. "ðɪs wɪl du."

Moiraine, hands still on the pommel, studied the building intently before nodding. "This will do."

læn lɛp fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl ən lɪftəd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ daʊn ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz. "bɹɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz ɪnsaɪd," hi kəmændəd. "faɪn ə ɹum ɪn ðə bæk tə juz fəɹ ə steɪbəl. muv, fɑɹmbɔɪz. ðɪs ɪzən ðə vɪlədʒ ɡɹin." hi vænɪʃt ɪnsaɪd kæɹiɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Lan leaped from his saddle and lifted the Aes Sedai down in his arms. "Bring the horses inside," he commanded. "Find a room in the back to use for a stable. Move, farmboys. This isn't the village green." He vanished inside carrying the Aes Sedai.

nɪneɪiv skɹæmbəl daʊn ən hɝiɾ æftɝ hɪm, klʌtʃɪŋ əɹ bæɡ ʌv ɝbz ən ɔɪnmənts. ɛɡwin wɑz ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn hɝ. ðeɪ lɛf ðɛɹ maʊns stændɪŋ.

Nynaeve scrambled down and hurried after him, clutching her bag of herbs and ointments. Egwene was right behind her. They left their mounts standing.

" 'bɹɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz ɪnsaɪd,' " tɑm mʌɾɝd ɹaɪli, ən pʌft aʊɾ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz. hi klaɪm daʊn, stɪf ən sloʊ, nʌkəld ɪz bæk, ən ɡeɪv ə lɔŋ saɪ, ðən tʊk ɑldibz ɹeɪnz. "wɛl?" hi sɛd, lɪftɪŋ ən aɪbɹaʊ ət ɹænd ən ɪz fɹɛnz.

" 'Bring the horses inside,' " Thom muttered wryly, and puffed out his mustaches. He climbed down, stiff and slow, knuckled his back, and gave a long sigh, then took Aldieb's reins. "Well?" he said, lifting an eyebrow at Rand and his friends.

ðeɪ hɝid tə dɪsmaʊnt, ən ɡæðɝɾ ʌp ðə ɹɛst ə ðə hɔɹsəz. ðə dɔɹweɪ, wɪθaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə seɪ ðəɹ hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn ə dɔɹ ɪn ɪt, wɑz mɔɹ ðən bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə ɡɛt ði ænəməlz θɹu, ivən tu əbɹɛst.

They hurried to dismount, and gathered up the rest of the horses. The doorway, without anything to say there had ever been a door in it, was more than big enough to get the animals through, even two abreast.

ɪnsaɪd wɑz ə hjudʒ ɹum, əz waɪɾ əz ðə bɪldɪŋ, wɪð ə dɝɾi taɪl flɔɹ ən ə fju ɹæɡəd wɔl hæŋʒɪŋz, feɪɾəd tə ə dʌl bɹaʊn, ðət lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ wəd fɔl əpɑɹɾ əɾ ə tʌtʃ. nʌθɪŋ ɛls. læn hæd meɪɾ ə pleɪs ɪn ðə nɪɹəs kɔɹnɝ fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn wɪð ɪz kloʊk ən hɝz. nɪneɪiv, mʌɾɝɪŋ əbaʊt ðə dʌst, nɛl bɪsaɪd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, dɪɡɪŋ ɪn əɹ bæɡ, wɪtʃ ɛɡwin hɛld oʊpən.

Inside was a huge room, as wide as the building, with a dirty tile floor and a few ragged wall hangings, faded to a dull brown, that looked as if they would fall apart at a touch. Nothing else. Lan had made a place in the nearest corner for Moiraine with his cloak and hers. Nynaeve, muttering about the dust, knelt beside the Aes Sedai, digging in her bag, which Egwene held open.

"aɪ meɪ nɑt laɪk hɝ, ɪts tʃɹu," nɪneɪiv wɑz seɪɪŋ tə ðə wɔɹɾɝ əz ɹænd, liɾɪŋ bɛlə ən klaʊd, keɪm ɪn bɪhaɪn tɑm, "bʌɾ aɪ hɛlp ɛniwʌn u nidz maɪ hɛlp, wɛðɝ aɪ laɪk əm əɹ nɑt."

"I may not like her, it is true," Nynaeve was saying to the Warder as Rand, leading Bela and Cloud, came in behind Thom, "but I help anyone who needs my help, whether I like them or not."

"aɪ meɪd noʊ ækjəzeɪʃən, wɪzdəm. aɪ oʊnli sɛd, hæv ə kɛɹ wɪð jəɹ ɝbz."

"I made no accusation, Wisdom. I only said, have a care with your herbs."

ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə lʊk fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ. "ðə fækt ɪz, ʃi nidz maɪ ɝbz, ən soʊ də ju." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz əsɛɹbɪk tə stɑɹt, ən ɡɹu mɔɹ tɑɹɾ əz ʃi spoʊk. "ðə fækt ɪz, ʃi kən oʊnli də soʊ mʌtʃ, ivən wɪð əɹ wʌn paʊɝ, ən ʃiz dʌn əbaʊɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ʃi kən wɪθaʊt kəlæpsɪŋ. ðə fækt ɪz, jəɹ sɔɹd kænɑt hɛlp əɹ naʊ, lɔɹɾ ə ðə sɛvən taʊɝz, bʌt maɪ ɝbz kæn."

She gave him a look from the corner of her eye. "The fact is, she needs my herbs, and so do you." Her voice was acerbic to start, and grew more tart as she spoke. "The fact is, she can only do so much, even with her One Power, and she has done about as much as she can without collapsing. The fact is, your sword cannot help her now, Lord of the Seven Towers, but my herbs can."

mɔɪɹeɪn leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn lænz ɑɹm. "bi əɾ iz, læn. ʃi minz noʊ hɑɹm. ʃi sɪmpli dʌz nɑt noʊ." ðə wɔɹɾɝ snɔɹɾɪd dɝɪsɪvli.

Moiraine laid a hand on Lan's arm. "Be at ease, Lan. She means no harm. She simply does not know." The Warder snorted derisively.

nɪneɪiv stɑp dɪɡɪŋ ɪn əɹ bæɡ ən lʊkt ət hɪm, fɹaʊnɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tə mɔɪɹeɪn ʃi spoʊk. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ mɛni θɪŋz aɪ doʊnt noʊ. wʌt θɪŋ ɪz ðɪs?"

Nynaeve stopped digging in her bag and looked at him, frowning, but it was to Moiraine she spoke. "There are many things I don't know. What thing is this?"

"fɔɹ wʌn," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd, "ɔl aɪ tʃɹuli niɾ ɪz ə lɪɾəl ɹɛst. fəɹ ənʌðɝ, aɪ əɡɹi wɪð ju. jəɹ skɪlz ən nɑlədʒ wɪl bi mɔɹ jusfəl ðən aɪ θɔt. naʊ, ɪf juv sʌmθɪŋ ðət wɪl hɛlp mi slip fəɹ ən aʊɝ ən nɑt liv mi ɡɹɑɡi - ?"

"For one," Moiraine replied, "all I truly need is a little rest. For another, I agree with you. Your skills and knowledge will be more useful than I thought. Now, if you have something that will help me sleep for an hour and not leave me groggy - ?"

"ə wik ti ʌv fɑksteɪl, mɛɹɪsɪn, ən - "

"A weak tea of foxtail, marisin, and - "

ɹænd mɪs ðə læst ʌv ɪɾ əz i fɑloʊd tɑm ɪndə ə ɹum bɪhaɪn ðə fɝst, ə tʃeɪmbɝ dʒʌst əz bɪɡ ən ivən ɛmptiɝ. hɪɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə dʌst, θɪk ən ʌndɪstɝbd əntɪl ðeɪ keɪm. nɑɾ ivən ðə tʃɹæks ə bɝdz əɹ smɔl ænəməlz mɑɹk ðə flɔɹ.

Rand missed the last of it as he followed Thom into a room behind the first, a chamber just as big and even emptier. Here was only the dust, thick and undisturbed until they came. Not even the tracks of birds or small animals marked the floor.

ɹænd bɪɡæn tə ənsæɾəl bɛlə ən klaʊd, ən tɑm, ɑldib ən ɪz ɡɛldɪŋ, ən pɛɹɪn, hɪz hɔɹs ən mændɑɹb. ɔl bʌt mæt. hi dʒɹɑpt ɪz ɹeɪnz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum. ðəɹ wɝ tu dɔɹweɪz fɹəm ðə ɹum bɪsaɪdz ðə wʌn baɪ wɪtʃ ðeɪ hæɾ ɛntɝd.

Rand began to unsaddle Bela and Cloud, and Thom, Aldieb and his gelding, and Perrin, his horse and Mandarb. All but Mat. He dropped his reins in the middle of the room. There were two doorways from the room besides the one by which they had entered.

"æli," mæt ənaʊnst, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪz hɛd bæk ɪn fɹəm ðə fɝst. ðeɪ kəɾ ɔl si ðət mʌtʃ fɹəm wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ. ðə sɛkən dɔɹweɪ wɑz oʊnli ə blæk ɹɛktæŋɡəl ɪn ðə ɹɪɹ wɔl. mæt wɛn θɹu sloʊli, ən keɪm aʊt mʌtʃ fæstɝ, vɪɡɝəsli bɹʌʃɪŋ oʊl kɑbwɛbz aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛɹ. "nʌθɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ," hi sɛd, ɡɪvɪŋ ði æliweɪ ənʌðɝ lʊk.

"Alley," Mat announced, drawing his head back in from the first. They could all see that much from where they were. The second doorway was only a black rectangle in the rear wall. Mat went through slowly, and came out much faster, vigorously brushing old cobwebs out of his hair. "Nothing in there," he said, giving the alleyway another look.

"ju gɑnə teɪk kɛɹ ə jəɹ hɔɹs?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. hi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi fɪnɪʃt ɪz oʊn ən wɑz lɪftɪŋ ðə sæɾəl fɹəm mændɑɹb. stʃɹeɪnʒli, ðə fɪɹs-aɪd stæljən ɡeɪv ɪm noʊ tʃɹʌbəl əɾ ɔl, ðoʊ hi dɪd wɑtʃ pɛɹɪn. "noʊbɑdi ɪz gɑnə də ɪt fəɹ ju."

"You going to take care of your horse?" Perrin said. He had already finished his own and was lifting the saddle from Mandarb. Strangely, the fierce-eyed stallion gave him no trouble at all, though he did watch Perrin. "Nobody is going to do it for you."

mæt ɡeɪv ði æli wʌn læs lʊk ən wɛn tə hɪz hɔɹs wɪð ə saɪ.

Mat gave the alley one last look and went to his horse with a sigh.

əz ɹænd leɪd bɛləz sæɾəl ɑn ðə flɔɹ, hi noʊɾəst ðət mæt hæd teɪkən ɑn ə ɡlʌm stɛɹ. hɪz aɪz simd ə θaʊzən maɪlz əweɪ, ən i wɑz muvɪŋ baɪ ɹoʊt.

As Rand laid Bela's saddle on the floor, he noticed that Mat had taken on a glum stare. His eyes seemed a thousand miles away, and he was moving by rote.

"ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt, mæt?" ɹænd sɛd. mæt lɪftəd ðə sæɾəl fɹəm ɪz hɔɹs, ən stʊd hoʊldɪŋ ɪt. "mæt? mæt!"

"Are you all right, Mat?" Rand said. Mat lifted the saddle from his horse, and stood holding it. "Mat? Mat!"

mæt ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən ɔlmoʊs dʒɹɑp ðə sæɾəl. "wʌt? oʊ. aɪ . . . aɪ wɑz dʒʌs θɪŋkɪŋ."

Mat gave a start and almost dropped the saddle. "What? Oh. I . . . I was just thinking."

"θɪŋkɪŋ?" pɛɹɪn huɾɪd fɹəm wɛɹ i wɑz ɹɪpleɪsɪŋ mændɑɹbz bɹaɪɾəl wɪð ə hækɑmɔɹ. "ju wɝ əslip."

"Thinking?" Perrin hooted from where he was replacing Mandarb's bridle with a hackamore. "You were asleep."

mæt skaʊld. "aɪ wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt . . . əbaʊt wʌt hæpən bæk ðɛɹ. əbaʊt ðoʊz wɝdz aɪ. . . ." ɛvɹibɑɾi tɝn tə lʊk əɾ ɪm ðɛn, nɑt dʒʌst ɹænd, ən i ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli. "wɛl, jə hɝd wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. ɪts əz ɪf səm dɛd mæn wɑz spikɪŋ wɪð maɪ maʊθ. aɪ doʊn laɪk ɪt." hɪz skaʊl ɡɹu dipɝ wən pɛɹɪn tʃʌkəld.

Mat scowled. "I was thinking about . . . about what happened back there. About those words I. . . ." Everybody turned to look at him then, not just Rand, and he shifted uneasily. "Well, you heard what Moiraine said. It's as if some dead man was speaking with my mouth. I don't like it." His scowl grew deeper when Perrin chuckled.

"æɛmənz wɔɹkɹi, ʃi sɛd - ɹaɪt? meɪbi jəɹ æɛmən kʌm bæk əɡɛn. ðə weɪ jə ɡoʊ ɑn əbaʊt haʊ dʌl ɛmənz fild ɪz, aɪd θɪŋk jə wəd laɪk ðət - biɪŋ ə kɪŋ ən hɪɹoʊ ɹibɔɹn."

"Aemon's warcry, she said - right? Maybe you're Aemon come back again. The way you go on about how dull Emond's Field is, I'd think you would like that - being a king and hero reborn."

"doʊn seɪ ðæt!" tɑm dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ; ɛvɹibɑɾi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm naʊ. "ðæɾ ɪz deɪnʒɝəs tɔk, stupəd tɔk. ðə dɛd kən bi ɹibɔɹn, əɹ teɪk ə lɪvɪŋ bɑɾi, ən ɪts nɑt sʌmθɪŋ tə spik ə laɪtli." hi tʊk ənʌðɝ bɹɛθ tə kɑm hɪmsɛlf bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. "ði oʊl blʌd, ʃi sɛd. ðə blʌd, nɑɾ ə dɛd mæn. aɪv hɝd ðəɾ ɪt kən hæpən, səmtaɪmz. hɝd, ðoʊ aɪ nɛvɝ ɹɪli θɔt. . . . ɪt wɑz jəɹ ɹuts, bɔɪ. ə laɪn ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm jə tə jəɹ fɑðɝ tə jəɹ ɡɹændfɑðɝ, ɹaɪɾ ɑn bæk tə meɪnɛðɝən, ən meɪbi bɪɑnd. wɛl, naʊ jə noʊ jəɹ fæmli ɪz oʊld. jə ɔt tə lɛɾ ɪt ɡoʊ ət ðəɾ ən bi ɡlæd. moʊs pipəl doʊnt noʊ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ðən ðət ðeɪ hæɾ ə fɑðɝ."

"Don't say that!" Thom drew a deep breath; everybody stared at him now. "That is dangerous talk, stupid talk. The dead can be reborn, or take a living body, and it is not something to speak of lightly." He took another breath to calm himself before going on. "The old blood, she said. The blood, not a dead man. I've heard that it can happen, sometimes. Heard, though I never really thought. . . . It was your roots, boy. A line running from you to your father to your grandfather, right on back to Manetheren, and maybe beyond. Well, now you know your family is old. You ought to let it go at that and be glad. Most people don't know much more than that they had a father."

səm ʌv əs kæn ivən bi ʃʊɹ ə ðæt, ɹænd θɔt bɪɾɝli. meɪbi ðə wɪzdəm wɑz ɹaɪt. laɪt, aɪ hoʊp ʃi wɑz.

Some of us can't even be sure of that, Rand thought bitterly. Maybe the Wisdom was right. Light, I hope she was.

mæt nɑɾəd ət wʌt ðə ɡlimən sɛd. "aɪ səpoʊz aɪ ʃʊd. oʊnli . . . dʒju θɪŋk ɪts ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð wʌts hæpən tə ʌs? ðə tʃɹɑləks ən ɔl? aɪ min . . . oʊ, aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ aɪ min."

Mat nodded at what the gleeman said. "I suppose I should. Only . . . do you think it has anything to do with what's happened to us? The Trollocs and all? I mean . . . oh, I don't know what I mean."

"aɪ θɪŋk jə ɔt tə fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt, ən kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ seɪfli." tɑm pɹədust ɪz lɔŋ-stɛm paɪp fɹəm ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz kloʊk. "æn aɪ θɪŋk aɪm gɑnə hæv ə smoʊk." wɪð ə wæəl ə ðə paɪp ɪn ðɛɹ dɝɛkʃən, hi dɪsəpɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə fɹʌn ɹum.

"I think you ought to forget about it, and concentrate on getting out of here safely." Thom produced his long-stemmed pipe from inside his cloak. "And I think I am going to have a smoke." With a waggle of the pipe in their direction, he disappeared into the front room.

"wi ɑɹ ɔl ɪn ðɪs təɡɛðɝ, nɑt dʒʌst wʌn ʌv ʌs," ɹænd toʊl mæt.

"We are all in this together, not just one of us," Rand told Mat.

mæt ɡeɪv hɪmsɛlf ə ʃeɪk, ən læft, ə ʃɔɹt bɑɹk. "ɹaɪt. wɛl, spikɪŋ ə biɪŋ ɪn θɪŋz təɡɛðɝ, naʊ ðət wɝ dʌn wɪð ðə hɔɹsəz, waɪ doʊnt wi ɡoʊ si ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ə ðɪs sɪɾi. ə ɹil sɪɾi, ən noʊ kɹaʊdz tə dʒɑsəl jəɹ ɛlboʊ ən poʊk jə ɪn ðə ɹɪbz. noʊbɑdi lʊkɪŋ daʊn ðɛɹ lɔŋ noʊzɪz əɾ ʌs. ðɛɹz stɪl ən aʊɝ, meɪbi tu, ʌv deɪlaɪt lɛft."

Mat gave himself a shake, and laughed, a short bark. "Right. Well, speaking of being in things together, now that we're done with the horses, why don't we go see a little more of this city. A real city, and no crowds to jostle your elbow and poke you in the ribs. Nobody looking down their long noses at us. There's still an hour, maybe two, of daylight left."

"ɑɹən jə fɝɡɛɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks?" pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Aren't you forgetting the Trollocs?" Perrin said.

mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd skɔɹnfəli. "læn sɛd ðeɪ wʊdn kʌm ɪn hɪɹ, ɹɪmɛmbɝ? jə nid tə lɪsən tə wʌt pipəl seɪ."

Mat shook his head scornfully. "Lan said they wouldn't come in here, remember? You need to listen to what people say."

"aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "æn aɪ də lɪsən. ðɪs sɪɾi - ɑɹɪdhɔl? - wɑz ən ælaɪ ʌv meɪnɛðɝən. si? aɪ lɪsən."

"I remember," Perrin said. "And I do listen. This city - Aridhol? - was an ally of Manetheren. See? I listen."

"ɑɹɪdhɔl mʌst əv bɪn ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst sɪɾi ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz," ɹænd sɛd, "fɔɹ ðə tʃɹɑləks tə stɪl bi əfɹeɪɾ ʌv ɪt. ðeɪ wɝn əfɹeɪd tə kʌm ɪndə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ən mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd meɪnɛðɝən wɑz - haʊ dɪd ʃi pʊɾ ɪt? - ə θɔɹn tə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz fʊt."

"Aridhol must have been the greatest city in the Trolloc Wars," Rand said, "for the Trollocs to still be afraid of it. They weren't afraid to come into the Two Rivers, and Moiraine said Manetheren was - how did she put it? - a thorn to the Dark One's foot."

pɛɹɪn ɹeɪzd ɪz hænz. "doʊn mɛnʃən ðə ʃɛpɝɾ ə ðə naɪt. pliz?"

Perrin raised his hands. "Don't mention the Shepherd of the Night. Please?"

"wʌt dʒju seɪ?" mæt læft. "lɛts ɡoʊ."

"What do you say?" Mat laughed. "Let's go."

"wi ʃəɾ æsk mɔɪɹeɪn," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ən mæt θɹu ʌp ɪz hænz.

"We should ask Moiraine," Perrin said, and Mat threw up his hands.

"æsk mɔɪɹeɪn? jə θɪŋk ʃɪl lɛɾ əs aʊɾ ə hɝ saɪt? ən wʌɾ əbaʊt nɪneɪiv? blʌɾ ən æʃəz, pɛɹɪn, waɪ nɑɾ æsk mɪstʃɹəs luhən waɪl jəɹ əbaʊɾ ɪt?"

"Ask Moiraine? You think she'll let us out of her sight? And what about Nynaeve? Blood and ashes, Perrin, why not ask Mistress Luhhan while you're about it?"

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd ɹɪlʌktən əɡɹimənt, ən mæt tɝn tə ɹænd wɪð ə ɡɹɪn. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ju? ə ɹil sɪɾi? wɪð pæləsəz!" hi ɡeɪv ə slaɪ læf. "ænd noʊ waɪtkloʊks tə stɛɹ əɾ ʌs."

Perrin nodded reluctant agreement, and Mat turned to Rand with a grin. "What about you? A real city? With palaces!" He gave a sly laugh. "And no Whitecloaks to stare at us."

ɹænd ɡeɪv ɪm ə dɝɾi lʊk, bʌɾ i hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli ə mɪnət. ðoʊz pæləsəz wɝ laɪk ə ɡlimənz teɪl. "ɔl ɹaɪt."

Rand gave him a dirty look, but he hesitated only a minute. Those palaces were like a gleeman's tale. "All right."

stɛpɪŋ sɔfli soʊ əz nɑt tə bi hɝɾ ɪn ðə fɹʌn ɹum, ðeɪ lɛf baɪ ði æli, fɑloʊɪŋ ɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə fɹʌn ə ðə bɪldɪŋ tə ə stʃɹiɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd. ðeɪ wɔkt kwɪkli, ən wən ðeɪ wɝ ə blɑk əweɪ fɹəm ðə waɪt stoʊn bɪldɪŋ mæt sʌɾənli bɹoʊk ɪndə ə keɪpɝɪŋ dæns.

Stepping softly so as not to be heard in the front room, they left by the alley, following it away from the front of the building to a street on the other side. They walked quickly, and when they were a block away from the white stone building Mat suddenly broke into a capering dance.

"fɹi." hi læft. "fɹi!" hi sloʊɾ əntɪl i wɑz tɝnɪŋ ə sɝkəl, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ən stɪl læfɪŋ. ði æftɝnun ʃædoʊz stʃɹɛtʃt lɔŋ ən dʒæɡd, ən ðə sɪŋkɪŋ sʌn meɪd ðə ɹuən sɪɾi ɡoʊldən. "dɪd jə ɛvɝ ivən dʒɹim ʌv ə pleɪs laɪk ðɪs? dɪd ju?"

"Free." He laughed. "Free!" He slowed until he was turning a circle, staring at everything and still laughing. The afternoon shadows stretched long and jagged, and the sinking sun made the ruined city golden. "Did you ever even dream of a place like this? Did you?"

pɛɹɪn læft, tu, bʌt ɹænd ʃɹʌɡd ənkʌmftəbli. ðɪs wɑz nʌθɪŋ laɪk ðə sɪɾi ɪn ɪz fɝs dʒɹim, bʌt dʒʌs ðə seɪm. . . . "ɪf wɝ gɑnə si ɛniθɪŋ," hi sɛd, "wi hæd bɛɾɝ ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð ɪt. ðəɹ ɪzən mʌtʃ deɪlaɪt lɛft."

Perrin laughed, too, but Rand shrugged uncomfortably. This was nothing like the city in his first dream, but just the same. . . . "If we're going to see anything," he said, "we had better get on with it. There isn't much daylight left."

mæt wɑntəd tə si ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɪt simd, ən i pʊl ði ʌðɝz əlɔŋ wɪð ɪz ɪnθuziæzəm. ðeɪ klaɪmd oʊvɝ dʌsti faʊntənz wɪð beɪsənz waɪɾ ɪnʌf tə hoʊld ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪn ɛmənz fild ən wɑndɝɾ ɪn ən aʊɾ ə stʃɹʌktʃɝz tʃoʊzən ət ɹændəm, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz ðə bɪɡəs ðeɪ kəd faɪnd. səm ðeɪ ʌndɝstʊd, ən səm nɑt. ə pæləs wɑz pleɪnli ə pæləs, bʌt wʌt wɑz ə hjudʒ bɪldɪŋ ðət wɑz wʌn ɹaʊnd, waɪt doʊm əz bɪɡ əz ə hɪl aʊtsaɪɾ ən wʌn mɑnstʃɹəs ɹum ɪnsaɪd? ən ə wɔl pleɪs, oʊpən tə ðə skaɪ ən bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə hæv hɛld ɔl ʌv ɛmənz fild, sɝaʊndəd baɪ ɹoʊ ɑn ɹoʊ ɑn ɹoʊ ʌv stoʊn bɛntʃɪz?

Mat wanted to see everything, it seemed, and he pulled the others along with his enthusiasm. They climbed over dusty fountains with basins wide enough to hold everybody in Emond's Field and wandered in and out of structures chosen at random, but always the biggest they could find. Some they understood, and some not. A palace was plainly a palace, but what was a huge building that was one round, white dome as big as a hill outside and one monstrous room inside? And a walled place, open to the sky and big enough to have held all of Emond's Field, surrounded by row on row on row of stone benches?

mæt ɡɹu ɪmpeɪʃənt wən ðeɪ faʊnd nʌθɪŋ bʌt dʌst, əɹ ɹʌbəl, əɹ kʌlɝləs ɹæɡz ʌv wɔl hæŋʒɪŋz ðət kɹʌmbəld əɾ ə tʌtʃ. wʌns səm wʊɾən tʃɛɹz stʊd stækt əɡɛnst ə wɔl; ðeɪ ɔl fɛl tə bɪts wən pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd tə pɪk wʌn ʌp.

Mat grew impatient when they found nothing but dust, or rubble, or colorless rags of wall hangings that crumbled at a touch. Once some wooden chairs stood stacked against a wall; they all fell to bits when Perrin tried to pick one up.

ðə pæləsəz, wɪð ðɛɹ hjudʒ, ɛmpti tʃeɪmbɝz, səm ʌv wɪtʃ cʊɾə hɛl ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn wɪð ɹum tə spɛɹ ɑn ɛvɹi saɪɾ ən əbʌv əz wɛl, meɪd ɹænd θɪŋk tu mʌtʃ ə ðə pipəl u hæd wʌns fɪl ðɛm. hi θɔɾ ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz cʊɾə stʊɾ ʌndɝ ðət ɹaʊn doʊm, ən əz fəɹ ðə pleɪs wɪð ðə stoʊn bɛntʃɪz. . . . hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɪmædʒən i kəd si ðə pipəl ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz, stɛɹɪŋ ɪn dɪsəpɹuvəl ət ðə θɹi ɪntʃɹuɾɝz dɪstɝbɪŋ ðɛɹ ɹɛst.

The palaces, with their huge, empty chambers, some of which could have held the Winespring Inn with room to spare on every side and above as well, made Rand think too much of the people who had once filled them. He thought everybody in the Two Rivers could have stood under that round dome, and as for the place with the stone benches. . . . He could almost imagine he could see the people in the shadows, staring in disapproval at the three intruders disturbing their rest.

faɪnəli ivən mæt taɪɝd, ɡɹæn əz ðə bɪldɪŋz wɝ, ən ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðəɾ i hæd hæɾ oʊnli ən aʊɝz slip ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ. ɛvɹiwʌn bɪɡæn tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt. jɔnɪŋ, ðeɪ sæɾ ɑn ðə stɛps ʌv ə tɔl bɪldɪŋ fɹʌntɪd baɪ ɹoʊ ɑn ɹoʊ ʌv tɔl stoʊn kɑləmz ən ɑɹɡjuɾ əbaʊt wʌt tə də nɛkst.

Finally even Mat tired, grand as the buildings were, and remembered that he had had only an hour's sleep the night before. Everyone began to remember that. Yawning, they sat on the steps of a tall building fronted by row on row of tall stone columns and argued about what to do next.

"ɡoʊ bæk," ɹænd sɛd, "ænd ɡɛt səm slip." hi pʊt ðə bæk ə hɪz hæn əɡɛnst ɪz maʊθ. wən i kəd tɔk əɡɛn, hi sɛd, "slip. ðæts ɔl aɪ wɑnt."

"Go back," Rand said, "and get some sleep." He put the back of his hand against his mouth. When he could talk again, he said, "Sleep. That's all I want."

"ju kən slip ɛnitaɪm," mæt sɛd dətɝmənədli. "lʊk ət wɛɹ wi ɑɹ. ə ɹuən sɪɾi. tʃɹɛʒɝ."

"You can sleep anytime," Mat said determinedly. "Look at where we are. A ruined city. Treasure."

"tʃɹɛʒɝ?" pɛɹɪnz dʒɔz kɹækt. "ðɛɹ ɪzən ɛni tʃɹɛʒɝ hɪɹ. ðəɹ ɪzən ɛniθɪŋ bʌt dʌst."

"Treasure?" Perrin's jaws cracked. "There isn't any treasure here. There isn't anything but dust."

ɹænd ʃeɪɾɪd ɪz aɪz əɡɛns ðə sʌn, ə ɹɛd bɔl sɪɾɪŋ kloʊs tə ðə ɹuftɑps. "ɪts ɡɛɾɪŋ leɪt, mæt. ɪɾəl bi dɑɹk sun."

Rand shaded his eyes against the sun, a red ball sitting close to the rooftops. "It's getting late, Mat. It'll be dark soon."

"ðɛɹ kəd bi tʃɹɛʒɝ," mæt meɪnteɪn staʊtli. "ɛniweɪ, aɪ wɑnə klaɪm wʌn ə ðə taʊɝz. lʊk ət ðət wʌn oʊvɝ ðɛɹ. ɪts hoʊl. əl bɛt jə kəd si fəɹ maɪlz fɹəm ʌp ðɛɹ. wʌt dʒju seɪ?"

"There could be treasure," Mat maintained stoutly. "Anyway, I want to climb one of the towers. Look at that one over there. It's whole. I'll bet you could see for miles from up there. What do you say?"

"ðə taʊɝz ɑɹ nɑt seɪf," sɛɾ ə mænz vɔɪs bɪhaɪn ðɛm.

"The towers are not safe," said a man's voice behind them.

ɹænd lɛp tə hɪz fiɾ ən spʌn ɝaʊn klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt, ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ dʒʌst əz kwɪk.

Rand leaped to his feet and spun around clutching his sword hilt, and the others were just as quick.

ə mæn stʊɾ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz əmʌŋ ðə kɑləmz ət ðə tɑp ə ðə stɛɹz. hi tʊk hæf ə stɛp fɔɹwɝd, ɹeɪzd ɪz hæn tə ʃild ɪz aɪz, ən stɛp bæk əɡɛn. "fɝɡɪv mi," hi sɛd smuðli. "aɪ hæv bɪn kwaɪɾ ə lɔŋ taɪm ɪn ðə dɑɹk ɪnsaɪd. maɪ aɪz ɑɹ nɑt jɛt juz tə ðə laɪt."

A man stood in the shadows among the columns at the top of the stairs. He took half a step forward, raised his hand to shield his eyes, and stepped back again. "Forgive me," he said smoothly. "I have been quite a long time in the dark inside. My eyes are not yet used to the light."

"hu ɑɹ ju?" ɹænd θɔt ðə mænz æksɛn saʊndəɾ ɑd, ivən æftɝ bɛɹlən; səm wɝdz i pɹənaʊnst stʃɹeɪnʒli, soʊ ɹænd kəd bɛɹli ʌndɝstæn ðɛm. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ hɪɹ? wi θɔt ðə sɪɾi wɑz ɛmpti."

"Who are you?" Rand thought the man's accent sounded odd, even after Baerlon; some words he pronounced strangely, so Rand could barely understand them. "What are you doing here? We thought the city was empty."

"aɪ æm mɔɹɾɪθ." hi pɔzd əz ɪf ɪkspɛktɪŋ əm tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə neɪm. wən nʌn ə ðɛm ɡeɪv ɛni saɪn ə duɪŋ soʊ, hi mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ ən wɛn ɑn. "aɪ kəɾ æsk ðə seɪm kwɛstʃənz ə ju. ðəɹ əz bɪn noʊ wʌn ɪn ɑɹɪdhɔl fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm. ə lɔŋ, lɔŋ taɪm. aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv θɔt tə faɪn θɹi jʌŋ mɛn wɑndɝɪŋ ɪts stʃɹits."

"I am Mordeth." He paused as if expecting them to recognize the name. When none of them gave any sign of doing so, he muttered something under his breath and went on. "I could ask the same questions of you. There has been no one in Aridhol for a long time. A long, long time. I would not have thought to find three young men wandering its streets."

"wɝ ɑn əɹ weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn," ɹænd sɛd. "wi stɑp tə teɪk ʃɛltɝ fəɹ ðə naɪt."

"We're on our way to Caemlyn," Rand said. "We stopped to take shelter for the night."

"keɪɛmlɪn," mɔɹɾɪθ sɛd sloʊli, ɹoʊlɪŋ ðə neɪm ɝaʊn ɪz tʌŋ, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ʃɛltɝ fəɹ ðə naɪt, jə seɪ? pɝhæps jəl dʒɔɪn mi."

"Caemlyn," Mordeth said slowly, rolling the name around his tongue, then shook his head. "Shelter for the night, you say? Perhaps you will join me."

"ju stɪl hævən sɛd wʌt jəɹ duɪŋ hɪɹ," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"You still haven't said what you're doing here," Perrin said.

"waɪ, aɪm ə tʃɹɛʒɝ hʌntɝ, ʌv kɔɹs."

"Why, I am a treasure hunter, of course."

"hæv jə faʊn ɛni?" mæt dɪmændəɾ ɪksaɪɾədli.

"Have you found any?" Mat demanded excitedly.

ɹænd θɔt mɔɹɾɪθ smaɪld, bʌɾ ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz i kəd nɑt bi ʃʊɹ. "aɪ hæv," ðə mæn sɛd. "mɔɹ ðən aɪ ɪkspɛktəd. mʌtʃ mɔɹ. mɔɹ ðən aɪ kən kæɹi əweɪ. aɪ nɛvɝ ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn θɹi stʃɹɔŋ, hɛlθi jʌŋ mɛn. ɪf jəl hɛlp mi muv wʌɾ aɪ kən teɪk tə wɛɹ maɪ hɔɹsəz ɑɹ, jə meɪ itʃ əv ə ʃɛɹ ə ðə ɹɛst. əz mʌtʃ əz jə kən kæɹi. wʌtɛvɝ aɪ liv wɪl bi ɡɔn, kæɹiɾ ɔf baɪ səm ʌðɝ tʃɹɛʒɝ hʌntɝ, bɪfɔɹ aɪ kən ɹɪtɝn fəɹ ɪt."

Rand thought Mordeth smiled, but in the shadows he could not be sure. "I have," the man said. "More than I expected. Much more. More than I can carry away. I never expected to find three strong, healthy young men. If you will help me move what I can take to where my horses are, you may each have a share of the rest. As much as you can carry. Whatever I leave will be gone, carried off by some other treasure hunter, before I can return for it."

"aɪ toʊl jə ðəɹ mʌs bi tʃɹɛʒɝ ɪn ə pleɪs laɪk ðɪs," mæt ɪkskleɪmd. hi dɑɹɾɪd ʌp ðə stɛɹz. "wil hɛlp jə kæɹi ɪt. dʒʌs teɪk əs tə ɪt." hi ən mɔɹɾɪθ muv dipɝ ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊz əmʌŋ ðə kɑləmz.

"I told you there must be treasure in a place like this," Mat exclaimed. He darted up the stairs. "We'll help you carry it. Just take us to it." He and Mordeth moved deeper into the shadows among the columns.

ɹænd lʊkt ət pɛɹɪn. "wi kæn liv hɪm." pɛɹɪn ɡlænst ət ðə sɪŋkɪŋ sʌn, ən nɑɾəd.

Rand looked at Perrin. "We can't leave him." Perrin glanced at the sinking sun, and nodded.

ðeɪ wɛn ʌp ðə stɛɹz wɛɹəli, pɛɹɪn izɪŋ ɪz æks ɪn ɪts bɛlt lup. ɹændz hæn taɪɾənd ɑn ɪz sɔɹd. bʌt mæt ən mɔɹɾɪθ wɝ weɪɾɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə kɑləmz, mɔɹɾɪθ wɪð ɑɹmz foʊldəd, mæt piɹɪŋ ɪmpeɪʃənli ɪndə ði ɪntɪɹiɝ.

They went up the stairs warily, Perrin easing his axe in its belt loop. Rand's hand tightened on his sword. But Mat and Mordeth were waiting among the columns, Mordeth with arms folded, Mat peering impatiently into the interior.

"kʌm," mɔɹɾɪθ sɛd. "aɪ wɪl ʃoʊ jə ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ." hi slɪpt ɪnsaɪd, ən mæt fɑloʊd. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ði ʌðɝz tə də bʌt ɡoʊ ɑn.
