"Come," Mordeth said. "I will show you the treasure." He slipped inside, and Mat followed. There was nothing for the others to do but go on.

ðə hɔl ɪnsaɪd wɑz ʃæɾoʊi, bʌɾ ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli mɔɹɾɪθ tɝn əsaɪɾ ən tʊk səm nɛɹoʊ stɛps ðət waʊn ɝaʊn ən daʊn θɹu dipɝ ən dipɝ dɑɹk əntɪl ðeɪ fʌmbəl ðɛɹ weɪ ɪn pɪtʃ-blæknəs. ɹænd fɛlt əlɔŋ ðə wɔl wɪð wʌn hænd, ənʃʊɹ ðəɹ wəd bi ə stɛp bɪloʊ əntɪl ɪz fʊt mɛɾ ɪt. ivən mæt bɪɡæn tə fil ənizi, dʒʌdʒɪŋ baɪ hɪz vɔɪs wən i sɛd, "ɪts ɑfli dɑɹk daʊn hɪɹ."

The hall inside was shadowy, but almost immediately Mordeth turned aside and took some narrow steps that wound around and down through deeper and deeper dark until they fumbled their way in pitch-blackness. Rand felt along the wall with one hand, unsure there would be a step below until his foot met it. Even Mat began to feel uneasy, judging by his voice when he said, "It's awfully dark down here."

"jɛs, jɛs," mɔɹɾɪθ ɹɪplaɪd. ðə mæn sim tə bi hævɪŋ noʊ tʃɹʌbəl əɾ ɔl wɪð ðə dɑɹk. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ laɪts bɪloʊ. kʌm."

"Yes, yes," Mordeth replied. The man seemed to be having no trouble at all with the dark. "There are lights below. Come."

ɪndid ðə waɪndɪŋ stɛɹz əbɹʌpli ɡeɪv weɪ tə ə kɔɹəɾɝ dɪmli lɪt baɪ skæɾɝd, smoʊki tɔɹtʃɪz sɛɾ ɪn aɪɝn skɑnsɪz ɑn ðə wɔlz. ðə flɪkɝɪŋ fleɪmz ən ʃædoʊz ɡeɪv ɹænd ɪz fɝst ɡʊd lʊk ət mɔɹɾɪθ, hu hɝiɾ ɑn wɪθaʊt pɔzɪŋ, moʊʃənɪŋ əm tə fɑloʊ.

Indeed the winding stairs abruptly gave way to a corridor dimly lit by scattered, smoky torches set in iron sconces on the walls. The flickering flames and shadows gave Rand his first good look at Mordeth, who hurried on without pausing, motioning them to follow.

ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɑɾ əbaʊt hɪm, ɹænd θɔt, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt pɪk aʊt wʌɾ ɪt wɑz, ɪɡzækli. mɔɹɾɪθ wɑz ə slik, sʌmwʌɾ oʊvɝfɛd mæn, wɪð dʒɹupɪŋ aɪlɪdz ðət meɪɾ ɪm sim tə bi haɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn sʌmθɪŋ ən stɛɹɪŋ. ʃɔɹt, ən kəmplitli bɔld, hi wɔkt əz ɪf i wɝ tɔlɝ ðən ɛni ʌv ðɛm. hɪz kloʊðz wɝ sɝɾənli laɪk nʌθɪŋ ɹænd hæɾ ɛvɝ sin bɪfɔɹ, iðɝ. taɪt blæk bɹitʃɪz ən sɑft ɹɛd buts wɪð ðə tɑps tɝn daʊn əɾ ɪz æŋkəlz. ə lɔŋ, ɹɛd vɛs θɪkli ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɪn ɡoʊld, ən ə snoʊi waɪt ʃɝt wɪð waɪd slivz, ðə pɔɪns ə hɪz kʌfs hæŋɪŋ ɔlmoʊs tə hɪz niz. sɝɾənli nɑt ðə kaɪndə kloʊðz ɪn wɪtʃ tə hʌn θɹu ə ɹuən sɪɾi ɪn sɝtʃ ə tʃɹɛʒɝ. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt ðət wɪtʃ meɪɾ ɪm sim stʃɹeɪnʒ, iðɝ.

There was something odd about him, Rand thought, but he could not pick out what it was, exactly. Mordeth was a sleek, somewhat overfed man, with drooping eyelids that made him seem to be hiding behind something and staring. Short, and completely bald, he walked as if he were taller than any of them. His clothes were certainly like nothing Rand had ever seen before, either. Tight black breeches and soft red boots with the tops turned down at his ankles. A long, red vest thickly embroidered in gold, and a snowy white shirt with wide sleeves, the points of his cuffs hanging almost to his knees. Certainly not the kind of clothes in which to hunt through a ruined city in search of treasure. But it was not that which made him seem strange, either.

ðən ðə kɔɹəɾɝ ɛndəɾ ɪn ə taɪl-wɔld ɹum, ən i fɝɡɑɾ əbaʊɾ ɛni ɑɾətiz mɔɹɾɪθ maɪt hæv. hɪz ɡæsp wɑz ən ɛkoʊ ʌv ɪz fɹɛnz'. hɪɹ, tu, laɪt keɪm fɹəm ə fju tɔɹtʃɪz steɪnɪŋ ðə silɪŋ wɪð ðɛɹ smoʊk ən ɡɪvɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn mɔɹ ðən wʌn ʃædoʊ, bʌt ðət laɪt wɑz ɹəflɛktəɾ ə θaʊzən taɪmz baɪ ðə dʒɛmz ən ɡoʊl paɪld ɑn ðə flɔɹ, maʊnz ə kɔɪnz ən dʒuəlɹi, ɡoʊbləts ən pleɪts ən plæɾɝz, ɡɪldɪd, dʒɛm-ɛnkɹʌstɪd sɔɹdz ən dæɡɝz, ɔl hip təɡɛðɝ kɛɹləsli ɪn weɪst-haɪ maʊnz.

Then the corridor ended in a tile-walled room, and he forgot about any oddities Mordeth might have. His gasp was an echo of his friends'. Here, too, light came from a few torches staining the ceiling with their smoke and giving everyone more than one shadow, but that light was reflected a thousand times by the gems and gold piled on the floor, mounds of coins and jewelry, goblets and plates and platters, gilded, gem-encrusted swords and daggers, all heaped together carelessly in waist-high mounds.

wɪð ə kɹaɪ mæt ɹæn fɔɹwɝɾ ən fɛl tə hɪz niz ɪn fɹʌn ʌv wʌn ə ðə paɪlz. "sæks," hi sɛd bɹɛθləsli, pɔɪŋ θɹu ðə ɡoʊld. "wil nid sæks tə kæɹi ɔl ə ðɪs."

With a cry Mat ran forward and fell to his knees in front of one of the piles. "Sacks," he said breathlessly, pawing through the gold. "We'll need sacks to carry all of this."

"wi kæn kæɹi ɪɾ ɔl," ɹænd sɛd. hi lʊkt ɝaʊn hɛlpləsli; ɔl ðə ɡoʊl ðə mɝtʃəns bɹɔt tə ɛmənz fild ɪn ə jɪɹ wəd nɑɾ əv meɪd ðə θaʊzənθ pɑɹɾ ə dʒʌst wʌn ə ðoʊz maʊnz. "nɑt naʊ. ɪts ɔlmoʊs dɑɹk."

"We can't carry it all," Rand said. He looked around helplessly; all the gold the merchants brought to Emond's Field in a year would not have made the thousandth part of just one of those mounds. "Not now. It's almost dark."

pɛɹɪn pʊld ən æks fɹi, kɛɹləsli tɔsɪŋ bæk ðə ɡoʊl tʃeɪnz ðət hæd bɪn tæŋɡəld ɝaʊn ɪt. dʒuəlz ɡlɪɾɝd əlɔŋ ɪts ʃaɪni blæk hændəl, ən dɛləkət ɡoʊl skɹɑlwɝk kʌvɝd ðə twɪn bleɪdz. "təmɑɹoʊ, ðɛn," hi sɛd, hɛftɪŋ ði æks wɪð ə ɡɹɪn. "mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn wɪl ʌndɝstænd wən wi ʃoʊ ðɛm ðɪs."

Perrin pulled an axe free, carelessly tossing back the gold chains that had been tangled around it. Jewels glittered along its shiny black handle, and delicate gold scrollwork covered the twin blades. "Tomorrow, then," he said, hefting the axe with a grin. "Moiraine and Lan will understand when we show them this."

"ju ɑɹ nɑɾ əloʊn?" mɔɹɾɪθ sɛd. hi hæd lɛɾ əm ɹʌʃ pæst ɪm ɪndə ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ ɹum, bʌt naʊ hi fɑloʊd. "hu ɛls ɪz wɪð ju?"

"You are not alone?" Mordeth said. He had let them rush past him into the treasure room, but now he followed. "Who else is with you?"

mæt, ɹɪs dip ɪn ðə ɹɪtʃəz bɪfɔɹ hɪm, ænsɝɾ æbsənli. "mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn. ən ðən ðɛɹz nɪneɪiv, ən ɛɡwin, ən tɑm. hiz ə ɡlimən. wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn."

Mat, wrist deep in the riches before him, answered absently. "Moiraine and Lan. And then there's Nynaeve, and Egwene, and Thom. He's a gleeman. We're going to Tar Valon."

ɹænd kɑɾ ɪz bɹɛθ. ðən ðə saɪləns fɹəm mɔɹɾɪθ meɪɾ ɪm lʊk ət ðə mæn.

Rand caught his breath. Then the silence from Mordeth made him look at the man.

ɹeɪdʒ twɪstəd mɔɹɾɪθs feɪs, ən fɪɹ, tu. hɪz lɪps pʊl bæk fɹəm ɪz tiθ. "tɑɹ vəlɑn!" hi ʃʊk klɛntʃt fɪsts ət ðɛm. "tɑɹ vəlɑn! jə sɛd jə wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə ðɪs . . . ðɪs . . . keɪɛmlɪn! jə laɪd tə mi!"

Rage twisted Mordeth's face, and fear, too. His lips pulled back from his teeth. "Tar Valon!" He shook clenched fists at them. "Tar Valon! You said you were going to this . . . this . . . Caemlyn! You lied to me!"

"ɪf jə stɪl wɑnt," pɛɹɪn sɛd tə mɔɹɾɪθ, "wil kʌm bæk təmɑɹoʊ ən hɛlp ju." kɛɹfəli hi sɛt ði æks bæk ɑn ðə hip ə dʒɛm-ɛnkɹʌstɪd tʃæləsəz ən dʒuəlɹi. "ɪf jə wɑnt."

"If you still want," Perrin said to Mordeth, "we'll come back tomorrow and help you." Carefully he set the axe back on the heap of gem-encrusted chalices and jewelry. "If you want."

"noʊ. ðəɾ ɪz. . . ." pæntɪŋ, mɔɹɾɪθ ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz ɪf i kəd nɑt dɪsaɪd. "teɪk wʌt jə wɑnt. ɪksɛpt. . . . ɪksɛpt. . . ."

"No. That is. . . ." Panting, Mordeth shook his head as if he could not decide. "Take what you want. Except. . . . Except. . . ."

sʌɾənli ɹænd ɹilaɪzd wʌt hæd bɪn næɡɪŋ əɾ ɪm əbaʊt ðə mæn. ðə skæɾɝd tɔɹtʃɪz ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ hæd ɡɪvən itʃ ə ðɛm ə ɹɪŋ ə ʃædoʊz, dʒʌst əz ðə tɔɹtʃɪz ɪn ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ ɹum dɪd. oʊnli. . . . hi wɑz soʊ ʃɑkt i sɛɾ ɪɾ aʊt laʊd. "ju doʊn əv ə ʃædoʊ."

Suddenly Rand realized what had been nagging at him about the man. The scattered torches in the hallway had given each of them a ring of shadows, just as the torches in the treasure room did. Only. . . . He was so shocked he said it out loud. "You don't have a shadow."

ə ɡɑblət fɛl fɹəm mæts hænd wɪð ə kɹæʃ.

A goblet fell from Mat's hand with a crash.

mɔɹɾɪθ nɑɾəd, ən fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪz flɛʃi aɪlɪdz oʊpən ɔl ðə weɪ. hɪz slik feɪs sʌɾənli əpɪɹd pɪntʃt ən hʌŋɡɹi. "soʊ." hi stʊd stʃɹeɪɾɝ, simɪŋ tɔlɝ. "ɪɾ ɪz dɪsaɪɾɪd." əbɹʌpli ðəɹ wɑz noʊ simɪŋ tə ɪt. laɪk ə bəlun mɔɹɾɪθ swɛld, dɪstɔɹɾəd, hɛd pɹɛst əɡɛns ðə silɪŋ, ʃoʊldɝz bʌɾɪŋ ðə wɔlz, fɪlɪŋ ði ɛn ə ðə ɹum, kʌɾɪŋ ɔf ɪskeɪp. hɑloʊ-tʃikt, tiθ bɛɹɾ ɪn ə ɹɪktəs snɑɹl, hi ɹitʃt aʊt wɪð hænz bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə ɪnɡʌlf ə mænz hɛd.

Mordeth nodded, and for the first time his fleshy eyelids opened all the way. His sleek face suddenly appeared pinched and hungry. "So." He stood straighter, seeming taller. "It is decided." Abruptly there was no seeming to it. Like a balloon Mordeth swelled, distorted, head pressed against the ceiling, shoulders butting the walls, filling the end of the room, cutting off escape. Hollow-cheeked, teeth bared in a rictus snarl, he reached out with hands big enough to engulf a man's head.

wɪð ə jɛl ɹænd lɛp bæk. hɪz fit tæŋɡəld ɪn ə ɡoʊl tʃeɪn, ən i kɹæʃt tə ðə flɔɹ, ðə wɪnd nɑkt aʊɾ ə hɪm. stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ fəɹ bɹɛθ, hi stʃɹʌɡəld ət ðə seɪm taɪm fəɹ ɪz sɔɹd, faɪɾɪŋ ɪz kloʊk, wɪtʃ hæd bɪkʌm ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðə hɪlt. ðə jɛlz ə hɪz fɹɛnz fɪl ðə ɹum, ən ðə klæʃ ʌv ɡoʊl plæɾɝz ən ɡoʊbləts klæɾɝɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ. sʌɾənli ən æɡənaɪz skɹim ʃɪvɝɾ ɪn ɹændz ɪɹz.

With a yell Rand leaped back. His feet tangled in a gold chain, and he crashed to the floor, the wind knocked out of him. Struggling for breath, he struggled at the same time for his sword, fighting his cloak, which had become wrapped around the hilt. The yells of his friends filled the room, and the clash of gold platters and goblets clattering across the floor. Suddenly an agonized scream shivered in Rand's ears.

ɔlmoʊst sɑbɪŋ, hi mænədʒ tə ɪnheɪl ət læst, dʒʌst əz i ɡɑt ðə sɔɹɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɪts ʃiθ. kɔʃəsli, hi ɡɑt tə hɪz fit, wʌndɝɪŋ wɪtʃ ə hɪz fɹɛnz hæd ɡɪvən ðət skɹim. pɛɹɪn lʊk bæk əɾ ɪm waɪd-aɪd fɹəm əkɹɔs ðə ɹum, kɹaʊtʃt ən hoʊldɪŋ ɪz æks bæk əz ɪf əbaʊt tə tʃɑp daʊn ə tʃɹi. mæt pɪɹɾ ɝaʊn ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə tʃɹɛʒɝ paɪl, klʌtʃɪŋ ə dæɡɝ snætʃt fɹəm ðə tʃɹoʊv.

Almost sobbing, he managed to inhale at last, just as he got the sword out of its sheath. Cautiously, he got to his feet, wondering which of his friends had given that scream. Perrin looked back at him wide-eyed from across the room, crouched and holding his axe back as if about to chop down a tree. Mat peered around the side of a treasure pile, clutching a dagger snatched from the trove.

sʌmθɪŋ muvd ɪn ðə dipəs pɑɹɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊz lɛf baɪ ðə tɔɹtʃɪz, ən ðeɪ ɔl dʒʌmpt. ɪt wɑz mɔɹɾɪθ, klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz niz tə hɪz tʃɛst ən hʌɾəld əz dip ɪndə ðə fɝθəs kɔɹnɝ əz i kəd ɡɛt.

Something moved in the deepest part of the shadows left by the torches, and they all jumped. It was Mordeth, clutching his knees to his chest and huddled as deep into the furthest corner as he could get.

"hi tʃɹɪkt ʌs," mæt pæntɪd. "ɪt wɑz səm kaɪndə tʃɹɪk."

"He tricked us," Mat panted. "It was some kind of trick."

mɔɹɾɪθ θɹu bæk ɪz hɛɾ ən weɪld; dʌst sɪftɪd daʊn əz ðə wɔlz tʃɹɛmbəld. "ju ɑɹ ɔl dɛd!" hi kɹaɪd. "ɔl dɛd!" ən i lɛpt ʌp, daɪvɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɹum.

Mordeth threw back his head and wailed; dust sifted down as the walls trembled. "You are all dead!" he cried. "All dead!" And he leaped up, diving across the room.

ɹændz dʒɔ dʒɹɑpt, ən i ɔlmoʊs dʒɹɑp ðə sɔɹɾ əz wɛl. əz mɔɹɾɪθ dʌv θɹu ði ɛɹ, hi stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ən θɪnd, laɪk ə tɛnʒɹɪl ə smoʊk. əz θɪn əz ə fɪŋɡɝ i stʃɹʌk ə kɹæk ɪn ðə wɔl taɪlz ən vænɪʃt ɪndə ɪt. ə læs kɹaɪ hʌŋ ɪn ðə ɹum əz i vænɪʃt, feɪɾɪŋ sloʊli əweɪ æftɝ i wɑz ɡɔn.

Rand's jaw dropped, and he almost dropped the sword as well. As Mordeth dove through the air, he stretched out and thinned, like a tendril of smoke. As thin as a finger he struck a crack in the wall tiles and vanished into it. A last cry hung in the room as he vanished, fading slowly away after he was gone.

"ju ɑɹ ɔl dɛd!"

"You are all dead!"

"lɛts ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ," pɛɹɪn sɛd feɪnli, fɝmɪŋ ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ɪz æks waɪl i tʃɹaɪd tə feɪs ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən ət wʌns. ɡoʊld ɔɹnəməns ən dʒɛmz skæɾɝd ənnoʊɾɪst ʌndɝ ɪz fit.

"Let's get out of here," Perrin said faintly, firming his grip on his axe while he tried to face every direction at once. Gold ornaments and gems scattered unnoticed under his feet.

"bʌt ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ," mæt pɹətɛstəd. "wi kæn dʒʌs liv ɪt naʊ."

"But the treasure," Mat protested. "We can't just leave it now."

"aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛniθɪŋ ə hɪz," pɛɹɪn sɛd, stɪl tɝnɪŋ wʌn weɪ æftɝ ənʌðɝ. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs ən ʃaʊɾəd ət ðə wɔlz. "ɪts jəɹ tʃɹɛʒɝ, jə hɪɹ? wəɹ nɑt teɪkɪŋ ɛni ʌv ɪt!"

"I don't want anything of his," Perrin said, still turning one way after another. He raised his voice and shouted at the walls. "It's your treasure, you hear? We are not taking any of it!"

ɹænd stɛɹɾ æŋɡɹəli ət mæt. "du jə wɑn ɪm kʌmɪŋ æftɝ ʌs? əɹ ɑɹ jə gɑnə weɪt hɪɹ stʌfɪŋ jəɹ pɑkəts əntɪl i kʌmz bæk wɪð tɛn mɔɹ laɪk hɪm?"

Rand stared angrily at Mat. "Do you want him coming after us? Or are you going to wait here stuffing your pockets until he comes back with ten more like him?"

mæt dʒʌs dʒɛstʃɝd tə ɔl ðə ɡoʊld ən dʒuəlz. bɪfɔɹ i kəd seɪ ɛniθɪŋ, ðoʊ, ɹænd sizd wʌn ə hɪz ɑɹmz ən pɛɹɪn ɡɹæb ði ʌðɝ. ðeɪ hʌsəld ɪm aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum, mæt stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ əbaʊt ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ.

Mat just gestured to all the gold and jewels. Before he could say anything, though, Rand seized one of his arms and Perrin grabbed the other. They hustled him out of the room, Mat struggling and shouting about the treasure.

bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn tɛn stɛps daʊn ðə hɔl, ði ɔlɹɛɾi dɪm laɪt bɪhaɪn əm bɪɡæn tə feɪl. ðə tɔɹtʃɪz ɪn ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ ɹum wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ aʊt. mæt stɑpt ʃaʊɾɪŋ. ðeɪ heɪsən ðɛɹ stɛps. ðə fɝs tɔɹtʃ aʊtsaɪd ðə ɹum wɪŋkt aʊt, ðən ðə nɛkst. baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə waɪndɪŋ stɛɹz ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə dʒɹæɡ mæt ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ɹʌnɪŋ, wɪð ðə dɑɹk kloʊzɪŋ ɪn bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ivən ðə pɪtʃ-blæk ə ðə stɛɹz oʊnli meɪɾ əm hɛzəteɪɾ ən ɪnstənt, ðən ðeɪ spɛɾ ʌpwɝdz, ʃaʊɾɪŋ ət ðə tɑp ə ðɛɹ lʌŋz. ʃaʊɾɪŋ tə skɛɹ ɛniθɪŋ ðət maɪt bi weɪɾɪŋ; ʃaʊɾɪŋ tə ɹimaɪn ðɛmsɛlvz ðeɪ wɝ stɪl əlaɪv.

Before they had gone ten steps down the hall, the already dim light behind them began to fail. The torches in the treasure room were going out. Mat stopped shouting. They hastened their steps. The first torch outside the room winked out, then the next. By the time they reached the winding stairs there was no need to drag Mat any longer. They were all running, with the dark closing in behind them. Even the pitch-black of the stairs only made them hesitate an instant, then they sped upwards, shouting at the top of their lungs. Shouting to scare anything that might be waiting; shouting to remind themselves they were still alive.

ðeɪ bɝst aʊɾ ɪndə ðə hɔl əbʌv, slaɪɾɪŋ ən fɔlɪŋ ɑn ðə dʌsti mɑɹbəl, skɹæmbəlɪŋ aʊt θɹu ðə kɑləmz, tə tʌmbəl daʊn ðə stɛɹz ən læn ɪn ə bɹuz hip ɪn ðə stʃɹit.

They burst out into the hall above, sliding and falling on the dusty marble, scrambling out through the columns, to tumble down the stairs and land in a bruised heap in the street.

ɹænd əntæŋɡəl hɪmsɛlf ən pɪk tæmz sɔɹɾ ʌp fɹəm ðə peɪvmənt, lʊkɪŋ ɝaʊn ənizəli. lɛs ðən hæf ə ðə sʌn stɪl ʃoʊɾ əbʌv ðə ɹuftɑps. ʃædoʊz ɹitʃt aʊt laɪk dɑɹk hænz, meɪd blækɝ baɪ ðə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ laɪt, nɪɹli fɪlɪŋ ðə stʃɹit. hi ʃɪvɝd. ðə ʃædoʊz lʊk laɪk mɔɹɾɪθ, ɹitʃɪŋ.

Rand untangled himself and picked Tam's sword up from the pavement, looking around uneasily. Less than half of the sun still showed above the rooftops. Shadows reached out like dark hands, made blacker by the remaining light, nearly filling the street. He shivered. The shadows looked like Mordeth, reaching.

"æt list wɝ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt." mæt ɡɑɾ ʌp fɹəm ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə paɪl, dʌstɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɔf ɪn ə ʃeɪki ɪməteɪʃən ə hɪz juʒəwəl mænɝ. "æn ət list aɪ - "

"At least we're out of it." Mat got up from the bottom of the pile, dusting himself off in a shaky imitation of his usual manner. "And at least I - "

"ɑɹ wi?" pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Are we?" Perrin said.

ɹænd nu ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən ðɪs taɪm. ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk pɹɪkəld. sʌmθɪŋ wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ əm fɹəm ðə dɑɹknəs ɪn ðə kɑləmz. hi spʌn ɝaʊnd, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə bɪldɪŋz əkɹɔs ðə weɪ. hi kəd fil aɪz ɑn ɪm fɹəm ðɛɹ, tu. hɪz ɡɹɪp taɪɾənd ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt, ðoʊ hi wʌndɝd wʌt ɡʊɾ ɪt wəd bi. wɑtʃɪŋ aɪz sim tə bi ɛvɹiwɛɹ. ði ʌðɝz lʊkt ɝaʊnd wɛɹəli; hi nu ðeɪ kəd fil ɪt, tu.

Rand knew it was not his imagination this time. The back of his neck prickled. Something was watching them from the darkness in the columns. He spun around, staring at the buildings across the way. He could feel eyes on him from there, too. His grip tightened on his sword hilt, though he wondered what good it would be. Watching eyes seemed to be everywhere. The others looked around warily; he knew they could feel it, too.

"wi steɪ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə stʃɹit," hi sɛd hɔɹsli. ðeɪ mɛɾ ɪz aɪz; ðeɪ lʊkt əz fɹaɪɾənd əz i fɛlt. hi swɑloʊd hɑɹd. "wi steɪ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə stʃɹit, kip aʊɾ ə ʃædoʊz əz mʌtʃ əz wi kæn, ən wɔk fæst."

"We stay in the middle of the street," he said hoarsely. They met his eyes; they looked as frightened as he felt. He swallowed hard. "We stay in the middle of the street, keep out of shadows as much as we can, and walk fast."

"wɔk vɛɹi fæst," mæt əɡɹid fɝvənli.

"Walk very fast," Mat agreed fervently.

ðə wɑtʃɝz fɑloʊd ðɛm. əɹ ɛls ðəɹ wɝ lɑts ʌv wɑtʃɝz, lɑts ʌv aɪz stɛɹɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi bɪldɪŋ. ɹænd kəd nɑt si ɛniθɪŋ muv, hɑɹɾ əz i tʃɹaɪd, bʌɾ i kəd fil ði aɪz, iɡɝ, hʌŋɡɹi. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɪtʃ wəd bi wɝs. θaʊzənz ʌv aɪz, əɹ dʒʌst ə fju, fɑloʊɪŋ ðɛm.

The watchers followed them. Or else there were lots of watchers, lots of eyes staring out of almost every building. Rand could not see anything move, hard as he tried, but he could feel the eyes, eager, hungry. He did not know which would be worse. Thousands of eyes, or just a few, following them.

ɪn ðə stʃɹɛtʃəz wɛɹ ðə sʌn stɪl ɹitʃt ðɛm, ðeɪ sloʊd, dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl, skwɪntɪŋ nɝvəsli ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs ðəɾ ɔlweɪz sim tə leɪ əhɛd. nʌn ə ðɛm wɑz iɡɝ tə ɛntɝ ðə ʃædoʊz; noʊ wʌn wɑz ɹɪli ʃʊɹ sʌmθɪŋ maɪt nɑt bi weɪɾɪŋ. ðə wɑtʃɝz' æntɪsəpeɪʃən wɑz ə pælpəbəl θɪŋ wɛnɛvɝ ʃædoʊz stʃɹɛtʃt əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit, bɑɹɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ. ðeɪ ɹæn θɹu ðoʊz dɑɹk pleɪsəz ʃaʊɾɪŋ. ɹænd θɔɾ i kəd hɪɹ dʒɹaɪ, ɹʌslɪŋ læftɝ.

In the stretches where the sun still reached them, they slowed, just a little, squinting nervously into the darkness that always seemed to lay ahead. None of them was eager to enter the shadows; no one was really sure something might not be waiting. The watchers' anticipation was a palpable thing whenever shadows stretched across the street, barring their way. They ran through those dark places shouting. Rand thought he could hear dry, rustling laughter.

ət læst, wɪð twaɪlaɪt fɔlɪŋ, ðeɪ keɪm ɪn saɪɾ ə ðə waɪt stoʊn bɪldɪŋ ðeɪ hæd lɛft wʌt sim laɪk deɪz əɡoʊ. sʌɾənli ðə wɑtʃɪŋ aɪz dɪpɑɹɾəd. bɪtwin wʌn stɛp ən ðə nɛkst, ðeɪ vænɪʃt ɪn ə blɪŋk. wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd ɹænd bɹoʊk ɪndə ə tʃɹɑt, fɑloʊd baɪ hɪz fɹɛnz, ðən ə fʊl ɹʌn ðəɾ oʊnli ɛndəd wən ðeɪ hɛɹd θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ ən kəlæpst, pæntɪŋ.

At last, with twilight falling, they came in sight of the white stone building they had left what seemed like days ago. Suddenly the watching eyes departed. Between one step and the next, they vanished in a blink. Without a word Rand broke into a trot, followed by his friends, then a full run that only ended when they hared through the doorway and collapsed, panting.

ə smɔl faɪɝ bɝn ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə taɪl flɔɹ, ðə smoʊk vænɪʃɪŋ θɹu ə hoʊl ɪn ðə silɪŋ ɪn ə weɪ ðət ɹimaɪndəd ɹænd ənplɛzənli ʌv mɔɹɾɪθ. ɛvɹiwʌn ɪksɛp læn wɑz ðɛɹ, ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ðə fleɪmz, ən ðɛɹ ɹiækʃənz vɛɹid kənsɪɾɝəbli. ɛɡwin, wɔɹmɪŋ əɹ hænz ət ðə faɪɝ, ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ əz ðə θɹi bɝst ɪndə ðə ɹum, klʌtʃɪŋ əɹ hænz tə hɝ θɹoʊt; wən ʃi sɔ hu ɪt wɑz, ə ɹɪliv saɪ spɔɪld əɹ ətɛmpt əɾ ə wɪðɝɪŋ lʊk. tɑm mɪɹli mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪz paɪpɛstəm, bʌt ɹænd kɑt ðə wɝd "fulz" bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡlimən wɛn bæk tə poʊkɪŋ ðə fleɪmz wɪð ə stɪk.

A small fire burned in the middle of the tile floor, the smoke vanishing through a hole in the ceiling in a way that reminded Rand unpleasantly of Mordeth. Everyone except Lan was there, gathered around the flames, and their reactions varied considerably. Egwene, warming her hands at the fire, gave a start as the three burst into the room, clutching her hands to her throat; when she saw who it was, a relieved sigh spoiled her attempt at a withering look. Thom merely muttered something around his pipestem, but Rand caught the word "fools" before the gleeman went back to poking the flames with a stick.

"ju wʊl-hɛɾəd wɪɾəlɪŋz!" ðə wɪzdəm snæpt. ʃi bɹɪsəl fɹəm hɛd tə fʊt; hɝ aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd, ən bɹaɪt spɑts ə ɹɛd bɝn ɑn əɹ tʃiks. "waɪ ʌndɝ ðə laɪt dɪd jə ɹʌn ɔf laɪk ðæt? ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt? hæv jə noʊ sɛns əɾ ɔl? læn ɪz aʊt lʊkɪŋ fəɹ jə naʊ, ən jəl bi lʌkiɝ ðən jə dɪzɝv ɪf i dʌz nɑt paʊn səm sɛns ɪndə ðə lɑɾ ə jə wən i ɡɛts bæk."

"You wool-headed witlings!" the Wisdom snapped. She bristled from head to foot; her eyes glittered, and bright spots of red burned on her cheeks. "Why under the Light did you run off like that? Are you all right? Have you no sense at all? Lan is out looking for you now, and you'll be luckier than you deserve if he does not pound some sense into the lot of you when he gets back."

ði ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪs bɪtʃɹeɪd noʊ ædʒəteɪʃən əɾ ɔl, bʌɾ əɹ hænz hæd lust ə waɪt-nʌkəld ɡɹɪp ɑn əɹ dʒɹɛs ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðɛm. wʌtɛvɝ nɪneɪiv hæd ɡɪvən əɹ mʌst əv hɛlpt, fəɹ ʃi wɑz ɑn əɹ fit. "ju ʃəd nɑɾ əv dʌn wʌt jə dɪd," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə vɔɪs əz klɪɹ ən sɝin əz ə wɔɾɝwʊd pɑnd. "wi wɪl spik ʌv ɪt leɪɾɝ. sʌmθɪŋ hæpən aʊt ðɛɹ, əɹ jə wəd nɑt bi fɔlɪŋ ɔl oʊvɝ wʌn ənʌðɝ laɪk ðɪs. tɛl mi."

The Aes Sedai's face betrayed no agitation at all, but her hands had loosed a white-knuckled grip on her dress at the sight of them. Whatever Nynaeve had given her must have helped, for she was on her feet. "You should not have done what you did," she said in a voice as clear and serene as a Waterwood pond. "We will speak of it later. Something happened out there, or you would not be falling all over one another like this. Tell me."

"ju sɛɾ ɪt wɑz seɪf," mæt kəmpleɪnd, skɹæmbəlɪŋ tə hɪz fit. "ju sɛɾ ɑɹɪdhɔl wɑz ən ælaɪ ʌv meɪnɛðɝən, ən tʃɹɑləks wʊdn kʌm ɪndə ðə sɪɾi, ən - "

"You said it was safe," Mat complained, scrambling to his feet. "You said Aridhol was an ally of Manetheren, and Trollocs wouldn't come into the city, and - "

mɔɪɹeɪn stɛp fɔɹwɝd soʊ sʌɾənli ðət mæt kʌɾ ɔf wɪð ɪz maʊθ oʊpən, ən ɹænd ən pɛɹɪn pɔzd ɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ ʌp, hæfweɪ kɹaʊtʃt əɹ ɑn ðɛɹ niz. "tʃɹɑləks? dɪd jə si tʃɹɑləks ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz?"

Moiraine stepped forward so suddenly that Mat cut off with his mouth open, and Rand and Perrin paused in getting up, halfway crouched or on their knees. "Trollocs? Did you see Trollocs inside the walls?"

ɹænd swɑloʊd. "nɑt tʃɹɑləks," hi sɛd, ən ɔl θɹi bɪɡæn tɔkɪŋ ɪksaɪɾədli, ɔl ət ðə seɪm taɪm.

Rand swallowed. "Not Trollocs," he said, and all three began talking excitedly, all at the same time.

ɛvɹiwʌn bɪɡæn ɪn ə dɪfɹən pleɪs. mæt stɑɹɾəd wɪð faɪndɪŋ ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ, saʊndɪŋ ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf i hæd dʌn ɪɾ əloʊn, waɪl pɛɹɪn bɪɡæn ɪkspleɪnɪŋ waɪ ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn ɔf ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs wɪθaʊt tɛlɪŋ ɛniwʌn. ɹænd dʒʌmpt ɹaɪt tə wʌɾ i θɔt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, miɾɪŋ ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ əmʌŋ ðə kɑləmz. bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɔl soʊ ɪksaɪɾəd ðət noʊbɑdi toʊld ɛniθɪŋ ɪn ði ɔɹɾɝ ɪt hæpənd; wɛnɛvɝ wʌn ə ðɛm θɔɾ ə sʌmθɪŋ, hi blɝɾɪd ɪɾ aʊt wɪð noʊ ɹəɡɑɹd fəɹ wʌt keɪm bɪfɔɹ əɹ æftɝ, əɹ fəɹ u wɑz seɪɪŋ wʌt. ðə wɑtʃɝz. ðeɪ ɔl bæbəld əbaʊt ðə wɑtʃɝz.

Everyone began in a different place. Mat started with finding the treasure, sounding almost as if he had done it alone, while Perrin began explaining why they had gone off in the first place without telling anyone. Rand jumped right to what he thought was important, meeting the stranger among the columns. But they were all so excited that nobody told anything in the order it happened; whenever one of them thought of something, he blurted it out with no regard for what came before or after, or for who was saying what. The watchers. They all babbled about the watchers.

ɪt meɪd ðə hoʊl teɪl kloʊs tə ɪnkoʊhɪɹənt, bʌt ðɛɹ fɪɹ keɪm θɹu. ɛɡwin bɪɡæn kæstɪŋ ənizi ɡlænsɪz ət ði ɛmpti wɪndoʊz fɹʌntɪŋ ðə stʃɹit. aʊt ðəɹ ðə læst ɹɛmnəns ə twaɪlaɪt wɝ feɪɾɪŋ; ðə faɪɝ sim vɛɹi smɔl ən dɪm. tɑm tʊk ɪz paɪp fɹəm bɪtwin ɪz tiθ ən lɪsənd wɪð ɪz hɛd kɑkt, fɹaʊnɪŋ. mɔɪɹeɪnz aɪz ʃoʊd kənsɝn, bʌt nɑɾ ən əndu əmaʊnt. əntɪl. . . .

It made the whole tale close to incoherent, but their fear came through. Egwene began casting uneasy glances at the empty windows fronting the street. Out there the last remnants of twilight were fading; the fire seemed very small and dim. Thom took his pipe from between his teeth and listened with his head cocked, frowning. Moiraine's eyes showed concern, but not an undue amount. Until. . . .

sʌɾənli ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hɪst, ən ɡɹæbd ɹændz ɛlboʊ ɪn ə taɪt ɡɹɪp. "mɔɹɾɪθ! ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ ə ðət neɪm? bi vɛɹi ʃʊɹ, ɔl ə ju. mɔɹɾɪθ?"

Suddenly the Aes Sedai hissed, and grabbed Rand's elbow in a tight grip. "Mordeth! Are you sure of that name? Be very sure, all of you. Mordeth?"

ðeɪ mɝmɝɾ ə kɔɹuzd "jɛs," teɪkən əbæk baɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz ɪntɛnsəɾi.

They murmured a chorused "Yes," taken aback by the Aes Sedai's intensity.

"dɪɾ i tʌtʃ ju?" ʃi æskt əm ɔl. "dɪɾ i ɡɪv jə ɛniθɪŋ, əɹ dɪd jə də ɛniθɪŋ fəɹ hɪm? aɪ mʌs noʊ."

"Did he touch you?" she asked them all. "Did he give you anything, or did you do anything for him? I must know."

"noʊ," ɹænd sɛd. "nʌn ʌv ʌs. nʌn ə ðoʊz θɪŋz."

"No," Rand said. "None of us. None of those things."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd əɡɹimənt, ən æɾəd, "ɔl i dɪd wɑz tʃɹaɪ tə kɪl ʌs. ɪzən ðəɾ ɪnʌf? hi swɛld ʌp əntɪl i fɪl hæf ðə ɹum, ʃaʊɾəd ðət wi wɝ ɔl dɛd mɛn, ðən vænɪʃt." hi muvd ɪz hæn tə dɛmənstʃɹeɪt. "laɪk smoʊk." ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ə skwik.

Perrin nodded agreement, and added, "All he did was try to kill us. Isn't that enough? He swelled up until he filled half the room, shouted that we were all dead men, then vanished." He moved his hand to demonstrate. "Like smoke." Egwene gave a squeak.

mæt twɪstəɾ əweɪ pətʃələnli. "seɪf, jə sɛd! ɔl ðət tɔk əbaʊt tʃɹɑləks nɑt kʌmɪŋ hɪɹ. wʌt wɝ wi səpoʊz tə θɪŋk?"

Mat twisted away petulantly. "Safe, you said! All that talk about Trollocs not coming here. What were we supposed to think?"

"əpɛɹənli jə dɪd nɑt θɪŋk əɾ ɔl," ʃi sɛd, kuli kəmpoʊzd wʌns mɔɹ. "ɛniwʌn u θɪŋks wəd bi wɛɹi ʌv ə pleɪs ðət tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ əfɹeɪd tə ɛntɝ."

"Apparently you did not think at all," she said, coolly composed once more. "Anyone who thinks would be wary of a place that Trollocs are afraid to enter."

"mæts duɪŋ," nɪneɪiv sɛd, sɝɾənti ɪn əɹ vɔɪs. "hiz ɔlweɪz tɔkɪŋ səm mɪstʃəf əɹ ʌðɝ, ən ði ʌðɝz luz ðə lɪɾəl wɪts ðeɪ wɝ bɔɹn wɪð wən ðəɹ ɝaʊn hɪm."

"Mat's doing," Nynaeve said, certainty in her voice. "He's always talking some mischief or other, and the others lose the little wits they were born with when they're around him."

mɔɪɹeɪn nɑɾəd bɹifli, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz ɹɪmeɪn ɑn ɹænd ən ɪz tu fɹɛnz. "leɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, ən ɑɹmi kæmpt wɪðɪn ðiz ɹuənz - tʃɹɑləks, dɑɹkfɹɛnz, mɹdʒɹɑl, dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz, θaʊzənz ɪn ɔl. wən ðeɪ dɪd nɑt kʌm aʊt, skaʊts wɝ sɛn ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz. ðə skaʊts faʊnd wɛpənz, bɪts ʌv ɑɹmɝ, ən blʌd splæɾɝd ɛvɹiwɛɹ. ən mɛsədʒəz skɹætʃt ɑn wɔlz ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk tʌŋ, kɔlɪŋ ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌn tə eɪɾ əm ɪn ðɛɹ læst aʊɝ. mɛn u keɪm leɪɾɝ faʊnd noʊ tʃɹeɪs ə ðə blʌɾ əɹ ðə mɛsədʒəz. ðeɪ hæd bɪn skaʊɝɾ əweɪ. hæfmən ən tʃɹɑləks ɹɪmɛmbɝ stɪl. ðəɾ ɪz wʌt kips əm aʊtsaɪd ðɪs pleɪs."

Moiraine nodded briefly, but her eyes remained on Rand and his two friends. "Late in the Trolloc Wars, an army camped within these ruins - Trollocs, Darkfriends, Myrddraal, Dreadlords, thousands in all. When they did not come out, scouts were sent inside the walls. The scouts found weapons, bits of armor, and blood splattered everywhere. And messages scratched on walls in the Trolloc tongue, calling on the Dark One to aid them in their last hour. Men who came later found no trace of the blood or the messages. They had been scoured away. Halfmen and Trollocs remember still. That is what keeps them outside this place."

"æn ðɪs ɪz wɛɹ jə pɪk fəɹ əs tə haɪd?" ɹænd sɛɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif. "wid bi seɪfɝ aʊt ðəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə aʊtʃɹʌn ðɛm."

"And this is where you picked for us to hide?" Rand said in disbelief. "We'd be safer out there trying to outrun them."

"ɪf jə hæd nɑt ɡɔn ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd peɪʃənli, "ju wəd noʊ ðəɾ aɪ sɛt wɔɹdz ɝaʊn ðɪs bɪldɪŋ. eɪ mɹdʒɹɑl wəd nɑɾ ivən noʊ ðiz wɔɹdz wɝ ðɛɹ, fəɹ ɪts ə dɪfɹən kaɪndə ivəl ðeɪ ɑɹ mɛn tə stɑp, bʌt wʌt ɹɪzaɪdz ɪn ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ wɪl nɑt kɹɔs ðɛm, əɹ ivən kʌm tu nɪɹ. ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ɪɾəl bi seɪf fəɹ əs tə ɡoʊ; ðiz θɪŋz kænɑt stæn ðə laɪɾ ə ðə sʌn. ðəl bi haɪɾɪŋ dip ɪn ði ɝθ."

"If you had not gone running off," Moiraine said patiently, "you would know that I set wards around this building. A Myrddraal would not even know these wards were there, for it is a different kind of evil they are meant to stop, but what resides in Shadar Logoth will not cross them, or even come too near. In the morning it will be safe for us to go; these things cannot stand the light of the sun. They will be hiding deep in the earth."

"ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ?" ɛɡwin sɛɾ ənsɝteɪnli. "aɪ θɔt jə sɛd ðɪs sɪɾi wɑz kɔld ɑɹɪdhɔl."

"Shadar Logoth?" Egwene said uncertainly. "I thought you said this city was called Aridhol."

"wʌns ɪt wɑz kɔld ɑɹɪdhɔl," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd, "ænd wɑz wʌn ə ðə tɛn neɪʃənz, ðə lænz ðət meɪd ðə sɛkən kʌvənənt, ðə lænz ðət stʊɾ əɡɛns ðə dɑɹk wʌn fɹəm ðə fɝs deɪz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ɪn ðə deɪz wən θɔɹɪn ɑltɔɹən æl bæn wɑz kɪŋ ə meɪnɛðɝən, ðə kɪŋ ʌv ɑɹɪdhɔl wɑz beɪlwən meɪəl, beɪlwən aɪɝənhænd. ɪn ə twaɪlaɪɾ ə dɪspɛɹ dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, wən ɪt sim ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz mʌst ʃʊɹli kɑŋkɝ, ðə mæn kɔl mɔɹɾɪθ keɪm tə beɪlwənz kɔɹt."

"Once it was called Aridhol," Moiraine replied, "and was one of the Ten Nations, the lands that made the Second Covenant, the lands that stood against the Dark One from the first days after the Breaking of the World. In the days when Thorin al'Toren al Ban was King of Manetheren, the King of Aridhol was Balwen Mayel, Balwen Ironhand. In a twilight of despair during the Trolloc Wars, when it seemed the Father of Lies must surely conquer, the man called Mordeth came to Balwen's court."

"ðə seɪm mæn?" ɹænd ɪkskleɪmd, ən mæt sɛd, "ɪt kʊdn bi!" ə ɡlæns fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪn saɪləns ðɛm. stɪlnəs fɪl ðə ɹum ɪksɛp fəɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz vɔɪs.

"The same man?" Rand exclaimed, and Mat said, "It couldn't be!" A glance from Moiraine silenced them. Stillness filled the room except for the Aes Sedai's voice.

"bɪfɔɹ mɔɹɾɪθ hæd bɪn lɔŋ ɪn ðə sɪɾi hi hæd beɪlwənz ɪɹ, ən sun i wɑz sɛkən oʊnli tə ðə kɪŋ. mɔɹɾɪθ wɪspɝd pɔɪzən ɪn beɪlwənz ɪɹ, ən ɑɹɪdhɔl bɪɡæn tə tʃeɪnʒ. ɑɹɪdhɔl dʒɹu ɪn ɑn ɪtsɛlf, hɑɹɾənd. ɪt wɑz sɛd ðət səm wəd ɹæðɝ si tʃɹɑləks kʌm ðən ðə mɛn ʌv ɑɹɪdhɔl. ðə vɪktɝi ʌv ðə laɪɾ ɪz ɔl. ðət wɑz ðə bæɾəlkɹi mɔɹɾɪθ ɡeɪv ðɛm, ən ðə mɛn ʌv ɑɹɪdhɔl ʃaʊɾəd ɪt waɪl ðɛɹ didz əbændən ðə laɪt.

"Before Mordeth had been long in the city he had Balwen's ear, and soon he was second only to the King. Mordeth whispered poison in Balwen's ear, and Aridhol began to change. Aridhol drew in on itself, hardened. It was said that some would rather see Trollocs come than the men of Aridhol. The victory of the Light is all. That was the battlecry Mordeth gave them, and the men of Aridhol shouted it while their deeds abandoned the Light.

"ðə stɔɹi ɪz tu lɔŋ tə tɛl ɪn fʊl, ən tu ɡɹɪm, ən oʊnli fɹæɡməns ɑɹ noʊn, ivən ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. haʊ θɔɹɪnz sʌn, kɑɹ, keɪm tə wɪn ɑɹɪdhɔl bæk tə ðə sɛkən kʌvənənt, ən beɪlwən sæɾ ɪz θɹoʊn, ə wɪðɝd ʃɛl wɪð ðə laɪɾ ə mædnəs ɪn ɪz aɪz, læfɪŋ waɪl mɔɹɾɪθ smaɪld əɾ ɪz saɪɾ ən ɔɹɾɝd ðə dɛθs ə kɑɹ ən ði ɛmbəsi əz fɹɛnz ə ðə dɑɹk. haʊ pɹɪns kɑɹ keɪm tə bi kɔl kɑɹ wʌn-hænd. haʊ hi ɪskeɪp ðə dʌnʒənz ʌv ɑɹɪdhɔl ən flɛɾ əloʊn tə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz wɪð mɔɹɾɪθs ənnætʃɹəl əsæsənz əɾ ɪz hilz. haʊ ðəɹ i mɛt ɹiə, hu dɪd nɑt noʊ hu hi wɑz, ən mɛɹid hɝ, ən sɛt ðə skn ɪn ðə pæɾɝn ðət lɛd tə hɪz dɛθ əɾ əɹ hænz, ən hɝz baɪ hɝ oʊn hæn bɪfɔɹ ɪz tum, ən ðə fɔl ʌv ɑlɛθ-lɔɹil. haʊ ði ɑɹmiz ə meɪnɛðɝən keɪm tə əvɛnʒ kɑɹ ən faʊn ðə ɡeɪts ʌv ɑɹɪdhɔl tɔɹn daʊn, noʊ lɪvɪŋ θɪŋ ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ wɝs ðən dɛθ. noʊ ɛnəmi hæd kʌm tə ɑɹɪdhɔl bʌɾ ɑɹɪdhɔl. səspɪʃən ən heɪt hæd ɡɪvən bɝθ tə sʌmθɪŋ ðət fɛɾ ɑn ðət wɪtʃ kɹieɪɾəd ɪt, sʌmθɪŋ lɑkt ɪn ðə bɛdʒɹɑk ɑn wɪtʃ ðə sɪɾi stʊd. mɑʃəɾɝ weɪts stɪl, hʌŋɡɝɪŋ. mɛn spoʊk ʌv ɑɹɪdhɔl noʊ mɔɹ. ðeɪ neɪmd ɪt ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ðə ʃædoʊ weɪts, əɹ mɔɹ sɪmpli, ʃædoʊz weɪɾɪŋ.

"The story is too long to tell in full, and too grim, and only fragments are known, even in Tar Valon. How Thorin's son, Caar, came to win Aridhol back to the Second Covenant, and Balwen sat his throne, a withered shell with the light of madness in his eyes, laughing while Mordeth smiled at his side and ordered the deaths of Caar and the embassy as Friends of the Dark. How Prince Caar came to be called Caar One-Hand. How he escaped the dungeons of Aridhol and fled alone to the Borderlands with Mordeth's unnatural assassins at his heels. How there he met Rhea, who did not know who he was, and married her, and set the skein in the Pattern that led to his death at her hands, and hers by her own hand before his tomb, and the fall of Aleth-Loriel. How the armies of Manetheren came to avenge Caar and found the gates of Aridhol torn down, no living thing inside the walls, but something worse than death. No enemy had come to Aridhol but Aridhol. Suspicion and hate had given birth to something that fed on that which created it, something locked in the bedrock on which the city stood. Mashadar waits still, hungering. Men spoke of Aridhol no more. They named it Shadar Logoth, the Place Where the Shadow Waits, or more simply, Shadow's Waiting.

"mɔɹɾɪθ əloʊn wɑz nɑt kənsum baɪ mɑʃəɾɝ, bʌɾ i wɑz snɛɹd baɪ ɪt, ən hi, tu, hæz weɪɾəd wɪðɪn ðiz wɔlz θɹu ðə lɔŋ sɛntʃɝiz. ʌðɝz əv sin hɪm. səm hiz ɪnfluəns θɹu ɡɪfs ðət twɪs ðə maɪn ən teɪn ðə spɪɹət, ðə teɪnt wæksɪŋ ən weɪnɪŋ əntɪl ɪt ɹulz . . . əɹ kɪlz. ɪf ɛvɝ i kənvɪnsɪz sʌmwʌn tə əkʌmpəni hɪm tə ðə wɔlz, tə ðə baʊndɝi ʌv mɑʃəɾɝz paʊɝ, hɪl bi eɪbəl tə kənsum ðə soʊl ə ðət pɝsən. mɔɹɾɪθ wɪl liv, wɛɹɪŋ ðə bɑɾi ʌv ðə wʌn i wɝs ðən kɪld, tə ɹik ɪz ivəl ɑn ðə wɝld əɡɛn."

"Mordeth alone was not consumed by Mashadar, but he was snared by it, and he, too, has waited within these walls through the long centuries. Others have seen him. Some he has influenced through gifts that twist the mind and taint the spirit, the taint waxing and waning until it rules . . . or kills. If ever he convinces someone to accompany him to the walls, to the boundary of Mashadar's power, he will be able to consume the soul of that person. Mordeth will leave, wearing the body of the one he worse than killed, to wreak his evil on the world again."

"ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ," pɛɹɪn mʌmbəld wən ʃi stɑpt. "hi wɑntəɾ əs tə hɛlp kæɹi ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ tə hɪz hɔɹsəz." hɪz feɪs wɑz hæɡɝd. "aɪl bɛt ðeɪ wɝ səpoʊz tə bi aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi sʌmwɛɹ." ɹænd ʃɪvɝd.

"The treasure," Perrin mumbled when she stopped. "He wanted us to help carry the treasure to his horses." His face was haggard. "I'll bet they were supposed to be outside the city somewhere." Rand shivered.

"bʌt wəɹ seɪf, naʊ, ɑɹənt wi?" mæt æskt. "hi dɪdnt ɡɪv əs ɛniθɪŋ, ən i dɪdn tʌtʃ ʌs. wɝ seɪf, ɑɹənt wi, wɪð ðə wɔɹdz jə sɛt?"

"But we are safe, now, aren't we?" Mat asked. "He didn't give us anything, and he didn't touch us. We're safe, aren't we, with the wards you set?"

"wi ɑɹ seɪf," mɔɪɹeɪn əɡɹid. "hi kænɑt kɹɔs ðə wɔɹd laɪnz, nɔɹ kən ɛni ʌðɝ dɛnəzən ə ðɪs pleɪs. ən ðeɪ mʌs haɪd fɹəm ðə sʌnlaɪt, soʊ wi kən liv seɪfli wʌns ɪts deɪ. naʊ, tʃɹaɪ tə slip. ðə wɔɹdz wɪl pɹətɛkt əs əntɪl læn ɹɪtɝnz."

"We are safe," Moiraine agreed. "He cannot cross the ward lines, nor can any other denizen of this place. And they must hide from the sunlight, so we can leave safely once it is day. Now, try to sleep. The wards will protect us until Lan returns."

"hi hæz bɪn ɡɔn ə lɔŋ taɪm." nɪneɪiv lʊkt wɝidli ət ðə naɪɾ aʊtsaɪd. fʊl dɑɹk hæd fɔlən, əz blæk əz pɪtʃ.

"He has been gone a long time." Nynaeve looked worriedly at the night outside. Full dark had fallen, as black as pitch.

"læn wɪl bi wɛl," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd suðɪŋli, ən spɹɛɾ əɹ blæŋkəts bɪsaɪd ðə faɪɝ waɪl ʃi spoʊk. "hi wɑz plɛdʒ tə faɪt ðə dɑɹk wʌn bɪfɔɹ i lɛf ðə kɹeɪɾəl, ə sɔɹd pleɪst ɪn ɪz ɪnfən hænz. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ wəd noʊ ðə mɪnəɾ ə hɪz dɛθ ən ðə weɪ ʌv ɪt, dʒʌst əz i wəd noʊ maɪn. ɹɛst, nɪneɪiv. ɔl wɪl bi wɛl." bʌɾ əz ʃi wɑz ɹoʊlɪŋ hɝsɛlf ɪndə hɝ blæŋkəts, ʃi pɔzd, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə stʃɹiɾ əz ɪf ʃi, tu, wʊɾə laɪk tə noʊ wʌt kɛp ðə wɔɹɾɝ.

"Lan will be well," Moiraine said soothingly, and spread her blankets beside the fire while she spoke. "He was pledged to fight the Dark One before he left the cradle, a sword placed in his infant hands. Besides, I would know the minute of his death and the way of it, just as he would know mine. Rest, Nynaeve. All will be well." But as she was rolling herself into her blankets, she paused, staring at the street as if she, too, would have liked to know what kept the Warder.

ɹændz ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz fɛlt laɪk lɛɾ ən ɪz aɪz wɑntəd tə slaɪd ʃʌɾ ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn, jɛt slip dɪd nɑt kʌm kwɪkli, ən wʌns ɪt dɪd, hi dʒɹimd, mʌɾɝɪŋ ən kɪkɪŋ ɔf ɪz blæŋkəts. wən i woʊk, ɪt wɑz sʌɾənli, ən i lʊkt ɝaʊn fəɹ ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd wɛɹ i wɑz.

Rand's arms and legs felt like lead and his eyes wanted to slide shut on their own, yet sleep did not come quickly, and once it did, he dreamed, muttering and kicking off his blankets. When he woke, it was suddenly, and he looked around for a moment before he remembered where he was.

ðə mun wɑz ʌp, ðə læs θɪn slɪvɝ bɪfɔɹ ðə nu mun, ɪts feɪn laɪt dɪfiɾəd baɪ ðə naɪt. ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls wɑz stɪl əslip, ðoʊ nɑɾ ɔl saʊnli. ɛɡwin ən ɪz tu fɹɛnz twɪstəɾ ən mɝmɝɾ ɪnɔɾəbli. tɑmz snɔɹz, sɑft fəɹ wʌns, wɝ bɹoʊkən fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm baɪ hæf-fɔɹmd wɝdz. ðəɹ wɑz stɪl noʊ saɪn ə læn.

The moon was up, the last thin sliver before the new moon, its faint light defeated by the night. Everyone else was still asleep, though not all soundly. Egwene and his two friends twisted and murmured inaudibly. Thom's snores, soft for once, were broken from time to time by half-formed words. There was still no sign of Lan.

sʌɾənli hi fɛlt əz ɪf ðə wɔɹdz wɝ noʊ pɹətɛkʃən əɾ ɔl. ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl kəd bi aʊt ðəɹ ɪn ðə dɑɹk. tɛlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf i wɑz biɪŋ fulɪʃ, hi æɾəd wʊd tə ðə læs koʊlz ə ðə faɪɝ. ðə bleɪz wɑz tu smɔl tə ɡɪv mʌtʃ wɔɹmθ, bʌɾ ɪt ɡeɪv mɔɹ laɪt.

Suddenly he felt as if the wards were no protection at all. Anything at all could be out there in the dark. Telling himself he was being foolish, he added wood to the last coals of the fire. The blaze was too small to give much warmth, but it gave more light.

hi hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌt hæɾ əweɪkən ɪm fɹəm ɪz ənplɛzən dʒɹim. hi hæd bɪn ə lɪɾəl bɔɪ əɡɛn, kæɹiɪŋ tæmz sɔɹɾ ən wɪð ə kɹeɪɾəl stʃɹæp tə hɪz bæk, ɹʌnɪŋ θɹu ɛmpti stʃɹits, pɝsud baɪ mɔɹɾɪθ, hu ʃaʊɾəd ðəɾ i oʊnli wɑntəɾ ɪz hænd. ən ðəɹ hæd bɪn ən oʊl mæn u wɑtʃt əm ən kækəld wɪð mæd læftɝ ðə hoʊl taɪm.

He had no idea what had awakened him from his unpleasant dream. He had been a little boy again, carrying Tam's sword and with a cradle strapped to his back, running through empty streets, pursued by Mordeth, who shouted that he only wanted his hand. And there had been an old man who watched them and cackled with mad laughter the whole time.

hi ɡæðɝɾ ɪz blæŋkəts ən leɪ bæk, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə silɪŋ. hi wɑntəd vɛɹi mʌtʃ tə slip, ivən ɪf i hæd mɔɹ dʒɹimz laɪk ðə læst wʌn, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt meɪk ɪz aɪz kloʊs.

He gathered his blankets and lay back, staring at the ceiling. He wanted very much to sleep, even if he had more dreams like the last one, but he could not make his eyes close.

sʌɾənli ðə wɔɹɾɝ tʃɹɑɾəd saɪlənli aʊɾ ə ðə dɑɹknəs ɪndə ðə ɹum. mɔɪɹeɪn keɪm əweɪk ən sæɾ ʌp əz ɪf i hæd ɹʌŋ ə bɛl. læn oʊpən ɪz hænd; θɹi smɔl ɑbʒɛkts fɛl tə ðə taɪlz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ wɪð ðə klɪŋk ʌv aɪɝn. θɹi blʌd-ɹɛd bædʒɪz ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ə hɔɹn skʌlz.

Suddenly the Warder trotted silently out of the darkness into the room. Moiraine came awake and sat up as if he had rung a bell. Lan opened his hand; three small objects fell to the tiles in front of her with the clink of iron. Three blood-red badges in the shape of horned skulls.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ tʃɹɑləks ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz," læn sɛd. "ðeɪ wɪl bi hɪɹ ɪn lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ən aʊɝ. ən ðə dɑvɑl ɑɹ ðə wɝst ə ðɛm." hi bɪɡæn weɪkɪŋ ði ʌðɝz.

"There are Trollocs inside the walls," Lan said. "They will be here in little more than an hour. And the Dha'vol are the worst of them." He began waking the others.

mɔɪɹeɪn smuðli bɪɡæn foʊldɪŋ əɹ blæŋkəts. "haʊ mɛni? də ðeɪ noʊ wəɹ hɪɹ?" ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɝdʒənsi əɾ ɔl.

Moiraine smoothly began folding her blankets. "How many? Do they know we are here?" She sounded as if there were no urgency at all.

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðeɪ du," læn ɹɪplaɪd. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ wɛl oʊvɝ ə hʌnʒɹəd, fɹaɪɾənd ɪnʌf tə kɪl ɛniθɪŋ ðət muvz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðə hæfmən ɑɹ hævɪŋ tə dʒɹaɪv əm - fɔɹ dʒʌs tə hændəl wʌn fɪst - ən ivən ðə mɹdʒɹɑl sim tə wɑnt nʌθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən tə pæs θɹu ðə sɪɾi ən aʊɾ əz kwɪkli əz pɑsəbəl. ðeɪ ɑɹ nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ weɪ tə sɝtʃ, ən ðəɹ soʊ slɪpʃɑd ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt hɛɾɪŋ nɪɹli stʃɹeɪt fəɹ əs aɪ wəd seɪ wi hæd nʌθɪŋ tə wɝi əbaʊt." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd.

"I don't think they do," Lan replied. "There are well over a hundred, frightened enough to kill anything that moves, including one another. The Halfmen are having to drive them - four just to handle one fist - and even the Myrddraal seem to want nothing more than to pass through the city and out as quickly as possible. They are not going out of their way to search, and they're so slipshod that if they were not heading nearly straight for us I would say we had nothing to worry about." He hesitated.

"ðɛɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls?"

"There is something else?"

"oʊnli ðɪs," læn sɛd sloʊli. "ðə mɹdʒɹɑl fɔɹs ðə tʃɹɑləks ɪndə ðə sɪɾi. wʌt fɔɹs ðə mɹdʒɹɑl?"

"Only this," Lan said slowly. "The Myrddraal forced the Trollocs into the city. What forced the Myrddraal?"

ɛvɹiwʌn hæd bɪn lɪsnɪŋ ɪn saɪləns. naʊ tɑm kɝst ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, ən ɛɡwin bɹiðd ə kwɛstʃən. "ðə dɑɹk wʌn?"

Everyone had been listening in silence. Now Thom cursed under his breath, and Egwene breathed a question. "The Dark One?"

"doʊn bi ə ful, ɡɝl," nɪneɪiv snæpt. "ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪz baʊn ɪn ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl baɪ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ."

"Don't be a fool, girl," Nynaeve snapped. "The Dark One is bound in Shayol Ghul by the Creator."

"fɔɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ, ət list," mɔɪɹeɪn əɡɹid. "noʊ, ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz ɪz nɑɾ aʊt ðɛɹ, bʌt wi mʌs liv ɪn ɛni keɪs."

"For the time being, at least," Moiraine agreed. "No, the Father of Lies is not out there, but we must leave in any case."

nɪneɪiv aɪɾ əɹ nɛɹoʊli. "liv ðə pɹətɛkʃən ə ðə wɔɹdz, ən kɹɔs ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ɪn ðə naɪt."

Nynaeve eyed her narrowly. "Leave the protection of the wards, and cross Shadar Logoth in the night."

"ɔɹ steɪ hɪɹ ən feɪs ðə tʃɹɑləks," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "tə hoʊld əm ɔf hɪɹ wəd ɹikwaɪɝ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɪt wəd dɪstʃɹɔɪ ðə wɔɹdz ən ətʃɹæk ðə vɛɹi θɪŋ ðə wɔɹdz ɑɹ mɛn tə pɹətɛkt əɡɛnst. bɪsaɪdz, əz wɛl bɪld ə sɪɡnəl faɪɝ ətɑp wʌn ə ðoʊz taʊɝz fəɹ ɛvɹi hæfmən wɪðɪn twɛnti maɪlz. tə liv ɪz nɑt wʌɾ aɪ wəd tʃuz tə du, bʌt wəɹ ðə hɛɹ, ən ɪts ðə haʊnz u dɪkteɪt ðə tʃeɪs."

"Or stay here and face the Trollocs," Moiraine said. "To hold them off here would require the One Power. It would destroy the wards and attract the very thing the wards are meant to protect against. Besides, as well build a signal fire atop one of those towers for every Halfman within twenty miles. To leave is not what I would choose to do, but we are the hare, and it is the hounds who dictate the chase."

"wʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ mɔɹ aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz?" mæt æskt. "wʌɾ ɑɹ wi ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?"

"What if there are more outside the walls?" Mat asked. "What are we going to do?"

"wi wɪl juz maɪ ɝɪdʒənəl plæn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. læn lʊkt ət hɝ. ʃi hɛld ʌp ə hæn ən æɾəd, "wɪtʃ aɪ wɑz tu taɪɝd tə kæɹi aʊt bɪfɔɹ. bʌɾ aɪm ɹɛstəd, naʊ, θæŋks tə ðə wɪzdəm. wɪl meɪk fəɹ ðə ɹɪvɝ. ðɛɹ, wɪð əɹ bæks ɡɑɹɾəd baɪ ðə wɔɾɝ, aɪ kən ɹeɪz ə smɔlɝ wɔɹd ðət wɪl hoʊl ðə tʃɹɑləks ən hæfmən bæk əntɪl wi kən meɪk ɹæfs ən kɹɔs oʊvɝ. əɹ bɛɾɝ jɛt, wi meɪ ivən bi eɪbəl tə heɪl ə tʃɹeɪɾɝz boʊt kʌmɪŋ daʊn fɹəm sɑldɑiə."

"We will use my original plan," Moiraine said. Lan looked at her. She held up a hand and added, "Which I was too tired to carry out before. But I am rested, now, thanks to the Wisdom. We will make for the river. There, with our backs guarded by the water, I can raise a smaller ward that will hold the Trollocs and Halfmen back until we can make rafts and cross over. Or better yet, we may even be able to hail a trader's boat coming down from Saldaea."

ðə feɪsəz ə ði ɛmənz fildɝz lʊk blæŋk. læn noʊɾəst.

The faces of the Emond's Fielders looked blank. Lan noticed.

"tʃɹɑləks ən mɹdʒɹɑl loʊð dip wɔɾɝ. tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ tɛɹəfaɪɾ ʌv ɪt. niðɝ kən swɪm. eɪ hæfmən wɪl nɑt weɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən weɪs dip, ɪspɛʃli ɪf ɪts muvɪŋ. tʃɹɑləks woʊn də ivən ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ kən faɪn ɛni weɪ tə əvɔɪɾ ɪt."

"Trollocs and Myrddraal loathe deep water. Trollocs are terrified of it. Neither can swim. A Halfman will not wade anything more than waist deep, especially if it's moving. Trollocs won't do even that if they can find any way to avoid it."

"soʊ wʌns wi ɡɛɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ wɝ seɪf," ɹænd sɛd, ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ nɑɾəd.

"So once we get across the river we're safe," Rand said, and the Warder nodded.

"ðə mɹdʒɹɑl wɪl faɪn ɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əz hɑɹd tə meɪk ðə tʃɹɑləks bɪld ɹæfs əz ɪt wɑz tə dʒɹaɪv əm ɪndə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, ən ɪf ðeɪ tʃɹaɪ tə meɪk əm kɹɔs ði ɑɹɪnɛl ðət weɪ, hæf wɪl ɹʌn əweɪ ən ðə ɹɛs pɹɑbli dʒɹaʊn."

"The Myrddraal will find it almost as hard to make the Trollocs build rafts as it was to drive them into Shadar Logoth, and if they try to make them cross the Arinelle that way, half will run away and the rest probably drown."

"ɡɛt tə jəɹ hɔɹsəz," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "wi ɑɹ nɑɾ əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ jɛt."

"Get to your horses," Moiraine said. "We are not across the river yet."


tʃæptɝ twɛnti


CHAPTER 20

dʌst ɑn ðə wɪnd


Dust on the Wind

əz ðeɪ lɛf ðə waɪt stoʊn bɪldɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ nɝvəsli ʃɪftɪŋ hɔɹsəz, ði aɪsi wɪn keɪm ɪn ɡʌsts, moʊnɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɹuftɑps, wɪpɪŋ kloʊks laɪk bænɝz, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ θɪn klaʊdz əkɹɔs ðə θɪn slɪvɝ ə ðə mun. wɪð ə kwaɪət kəmæn tə steɪ kloʊs, læn lɛɾ ɔf daʊn ðə stʃɹit. ðə hɔɹsəz dænst ən tʌɡd ət ðə ɹeɪnz, iɡɝ tə bi əweɪ.

As they left the white stone building on their nervously shifting horses, the icy wind came in gusts, moaning across the rooftops, whipping cloaks like banners, driving thin clouds across the thin sliver of the moon. With a quiet command to stay close, Lan led off down the street. The horses danced and tugged at the reins, eager to be away.

ɹænd lʊkt ʌp wɛɹəli ət ðə bɪldɪŋz ðeɪ pæst, lumɪŋ naʊ ɪn ðə naɪt wɪð ðɛɹ ɛmpti wɪndoʊz laɪk aɪ sɑkəts. ʃædoʊz sim tə muv. əkeɪʒənəli ðəɹ wɑz ə klæɾɝ - ɹʌbəl tɑpəl baɪ ðə wɪnd. ət lis ði aɪz ɑɹ ɡɔn. hɪz ɹɪlif wɑz moʊməntɛɹi. waɪ ɑɹ ðeɪ ɡɔn?

Rand looked up warily at the buildings they passed, looming now in the night with their empty windows like eye sockets. Shadows seemed to move. Occasionally there was a clatter - rubble toppled by the wind. At least the eyes are gone. His relief was momentary. Why are they gone?

tɑm ən ði ɛmənz fildɝz meɪɾ ə klʌstɝ wɪð hɪm, ɔl kipɪŋ kloʊs ɪnʌf tə tʌtʃ wʌn ənʌðɝ. ɛɡwinz ʃoʊldɝz wɝ hʌntʃt, əz ɪf ʃi wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə iz bɛləz hʊvz tə ðə peɪvmənt. ɹænd dɪd nɑɾ ivən wɑnə bɹið. saʊn maɪɾ ətʃɹækt ətɛnʃən.

Thom and the Emond's Fielders made a cluster with him, all keeping close enough to touch one another. Egwene's shoulders were hunched, as if she were trying to ease Bela's hooves to the pavement. Rand did not even want to breathe. Sound might attract attention.

əbɹʌpli hi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ə dɪstəns hæɾ oʊpən əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, sɛpɝeɪɾɪŋ əm fɹəm ðə wɔɹɾɝ ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə tu wɝ ɪndɪstɪŋkt ʃeɪps ə ɡʊd θɝɾi peɪsɪz əhɛd.

Abruptly he realized that a distance had opened ahead of them, separating them from the Warder and the Aes Sedai. The two were indistinct shapes a good thirty paces ahead.

"wɝ fɔlɪŋ bɪhaɪnd," hi mɝmɝd, ən buɾɪd klaʊd tə ə kwɪkɝ stɛp. ə θɪn tɛnʒɹɪl ə sɪlvɝ-ɡɹeɪ fɑɡ dʒɹɪftəd loʊ əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹiɾ əhɛɾ ə hɪm.

"We're falling behind," he murmured, and booted Cloud to a quicker step. A thin tendril of silver-gray fog drifted low across the street ahead of him.

"stɑp!" ɪt wɑz ə stʃɹæŋɡəld ʃaʊt fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪn, ʃɑɹp ən ɝdʒənt, bʌt pɪtʃt nɑt tə kæɹi fɑɹ.

"Stop!" It was a strangled shout from Moiraine, sharp and urgent, but pitched not to carry far.

ənsɝɾən, hi pʊld ʌp ʃɔɹt. ðə splɪntɝ ə fɑɡ leɪ kəmplitli əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit naʊ, sloʊli fæɾənɪŋ əz ɪf mɔɹ wɝ uzɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə bɪldɪŋz ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit. ɪt wɑz əz θɪk əz ə mænz ɑɹm naʊ. klaʊd wɪkɝɾ ən tʃɹaɪd tə bæk fɝðɝ əweɪ əz ɛɡwin ən tɑm ən ði ʌðɝz keɪm ʌp ɑn hɪm. ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, tu, tɔs ðɛɹ hɛdz ən bɹaɪɾəld əɡɛns kʌmɪŋ tu nɪɹ ðə fɑɡ.

Uncertain, he pulled up short. The splinter of fog lay completely across the street now, slowly fattening as if more were oozing out of the buildings on either side of the street. It was as thick as a man's arm now. Cloud whickered and tried to back further away as Egwene and Thom and the others came up on him. Their horses, too, tossed their heads and bridled against coming too near the fog.

læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn ɹoʊd sloʊli təwɔɹd ðə fɑɡ, ɡɹoʊn tə əz bɪɡ ɝaʊn əz ə lɛɡ, stɑpɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, wɛl bæk. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stʌɾid ðə bɹæntʃ ə mɪs ðət sɛpɝeɪɾəd ðɛm. ɹænd ʃɹʌɡd əɾ ə sʌɾən ɪtʃ ə fɪɹ bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz. ə feɪn laɪɾ əkʌmpənid ðə fɑɡ, ɡɹoʊɪŋ əz ðə fɑɡi tɛntəkəl bɪkeɪm fæɾɝ, bʌt stɪl oʊnli ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ðə munlaɪt. ðə hɔɹsəz ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli, ivən ɑldib ən mændɑɹb.

Lan and Moiraine rode slowly toward the fog, grown to as big around as a leg, stopping on the other side, well back. The Aes Sedai studied the branch of mist that separated them. Rand shrugged at a sudden itch of fear between his shoulder blades. A faint light accompanied the fog, growing as the foggy tentacle became fatter, but still only a little more than the moonlight. The horses shifted uneasily, even Aldieb and Mandarb.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" nɪneɪiv æskt.

"What is it?" Nynaeve asked.

"ði ivəl ə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "mɑʃəɾɝ. ənsiɪŋ, ənθɪŋkɪŋ, muvɪŋ θɹu ðə sɪɾi əz eɪmləsli əz ə wɝm bɝoʊz θɹu ði ɝθ. ɪf ɪt tʌtʃəz ju, jəl daɪ." ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz lɛt ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz dæns ə fju kwɪk stɛps bæk, bʌt nɑt tu fɑɹ. əz mʌtʃ əz ɹænd wʊɾə ɡɪvən tə bi fɹi ʌv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʃi wɑz əz seɪf əz hoʊm kəmpɛɹd tə wʌt leɪ ɝaʊn ðɛm.

"The evil of Shadar Logoth," Moiraine replied. "Mashadar. Unseeing, unthinking, moving through the city as aimlessly as a worm burrows through the earth. If it touches you, you will die." Rand and the others let their horses dance a few quick steps back, but not too far. As much as Rand would have given to be free of the Aes Sedai, she was as safe as home compared to what lay around them.

"ðɛn haʊ də wi dʒɔɪn ju?" ɛɡwin sɛd. "kæn jə kɪl ɪt . . . klɪɹ ə weɪ?"

"Then how do we join you?" Egwene said. "Can you kill it . . . clear a way?"

mɔɪɹeɪnz læf wɑz bɪɾɝ ən ʃɔɹt. "mɑʃəɾɝ ɪz væst, ɡɝl, əz væst əz ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ɪtsɛlf. ðə hoʊl waɪt taʊɝ kəd nɑt kɪl ɪt. ɪf aɪ dæmədʒd ɪɾ ɪnʌf tə lɛt jə pæs, dʒɹɔɪŋ ðət mʌtʃ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ wəd pʊl ðə hæfmən laɪk ə tʃɹʌmpət kɔl. ən mɑʃəɾɝ wəd ɹʌʃ ɪn tə hil wʌtɛvɝ hɑɹm aɪ dɪd, ɹʌʃ ɪn ən pɝhæps kætʃ əs ɪn ɪts nɛt."

Moiraine's laugh was bitter and short. "Mashadar is vast, girl, as vast as Shadar Logoth itself. The whole White Tower could not kill it. If I damaged it enough to let you pass, drawing that much of the One Power would pull the Halfmen like a trumpet call. And Mashadar would rush in to heal whatever harm I did, rush in and perhaps catch us in its net."

ɹænd ɪkstʃeɪnʒd lʊks wɪð ɛɡwin, ðən æskt əɹ kwɛstʃən əɡɛn. mɔɪɹeɪn saɪd bɪfɔɹ ænsɝɪŋ.

Rand exchanged looks with Egwene, then asked her question again. Moiraine sighed before answering.

"aɪ də nɑt laɪk ɪt, bʌt wʌt mʌs bi dʌn, mʌs bi dʌn. ðɪs θɪŋ wɪl nɑt bi əbʌv ɡɹaʊn ɛvɹiwɛɹ. ʌðɝ stʃɹits wɪl bi klɪɹ. si ðət stɑɹ?" ʃi twɪstəɾ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl tə pɔɪn tə ə ɹɛd stɑɹ loʊ ɪn ði istɝn skaɪ. "kip ɑn təwɔɹd ðət stɑɹ, ən ɪɾəl bɹɪŋ jə tə ðə ɹɪvɝ. wʌtɛvɝ hæpənz, kip muvɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪvɝ. ɡoʊ əz kwɪkli əz jə kæn, bʌɾ əbʌv ɔl meɪk noʊ nɔɪz. ðəɹ ɑɹ stɪl ðə tʃɹɑləks, ɹɪmɛmbɝ. ən fɔɹ hæfmən."

"I do not like it, but what must be done, must be done. This thing will not be above ground everywhere. Other streets will be clear. See that star?" She twisted in her saddle to point to a red star low in the eastern sky. "Keep on toward that star, and it will bring you to the river. Whatever happens, keep moving toward the river. Go as quickly as you can, but above all make no noise. There are still the Trollocs, remember. And four Halfmen."

"bʌt haʊ wɪl wi faɪn jə əɡɛn?" ɛɡwin pɹətɛstəd.

"But how will we find you again?" Egwene protested.

"aɪ wɪl faɪn ju," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "bi əʃʊɹd, aɪ kən faɪn ju. naʊ bi ɔf. ðɪs θɪŋ ɪz ʌɾɝli maɪnləs, bʌɾ ɪt kən sɛns fud." ɪndid, ɹoʊps ə sɪlvɝ-ɡɹeɪ hæd lɪftəd fɹəm ðə lɑɹdʒɝ bɑɾi. ðeɪ dʒɹɪftəd, weɪvɝɪŋ, laɪk ðə tɛntəkəlz ʌv ə hʌnʒɹdʒɹmz ɑn ðə bɑɾəm ʌv ə wɔɾɝwʊd pɑnd.

"I will find you," Moiraine said. "Be assured, I can find you. Now be off. This thing is utterly mindless, but it can sense food." Indeed, ropes of silver-gray had lifted from the larger body. They drifted, wavering, like the tentacles of a hundredarms on the bottom of a Waterwood pond.

wən ɹænd lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ðə θɪk tʃɹʌŋk ʌv oʊpeɪk mɪst, ðə wɔɹɾɝ ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɡɔn. hi lɪkt ɪz lɪps ən mɛɾ ɪz kəmpænjənz' aɪz. ðeɪ wɝ əz nɝvəs əz i wɑz. ən sʌmθɪŋ wɝs: ðeɪ ɔl sim tə bi weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ sʌmwʌn ɛls tə muv fɝst. naɪɾ ən ɹuənz sɝaʊndəd ðɛm. ðə feɪdz wɝ aʊt ðɛɹ, sʌmwɛɹ, ən ðə tʃɹɑləks, meɪbi ɝaʊn ðə nɛks kɔɹnɝ. ðə tɛntəkəlz ə fɑɡ dʒɹɪftəd nɪɹɝ, hæfweɪ tə ðɛm naʊ, ən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ weɪvɝɪŋ. ðeɪ hæd tʃoʊzən ðɛɹ ɪntɛndəd pɹeɪ. sʌɾənli hi mɪs mɔɪɹeɪn vɛɹi mʌtʃ.

When Rand looked up from the thick trunk of opaque mist, the Warder and the Aes Sedai were gone. He licked his lips and met his companions' eyes. They were as nervous as he was. And something worse: they all seemed to be waiting for someone else to move first. Night and ruins surrounded them. The Fades were out there, somewhere, and the Trollocs, maybe around the next corner. The tentacles of fog drifted nearer, halfway to them now, and no longer wavering. They had chosen their intended prey. Suddenly he missed Moiraine very much.

ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz stɪl stɛɹɪŋ, wʌndɝɪŋ wɪtʃ weɪ tə ɡoʊ. hi tɝn klaʊd, ən ðə ɡɹeɪ bɹoʊk ɪndə ə hæf tʃɹɑt, tʌɡɪŋ əɡɛns ðə ɹeɪnz tə ɡoʊ fæstɝ. əz ɪf muvɪŋ fɝs hæd meɪɾ ɪm ðə liɾɝ, ɛvɹiwʌn fɑloʊd.

Everyone was still staring, wondering which way to go. He turned Cloud, and the gray broke into a half trot, tugging against the reins to go faster. As if moving first had made him the leader, everyone followed.

wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn ɡɔn, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn tə pɹətɛkt əm ʃəd mɔɹɾɪθ əpɪɹ. ən ðə tʃɹɑləks. ænd. . . . ɹænd fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ. hi wəd fɑloʊ ðə ɹɛd stɑɹ. hi kəd hoʊld ɑntu ðət θɔt.

With Moiraine gone, there was no one to protect them should Mordeth appear. And the Trollocs. And. . . . Rand forced himself to stop thinking. He would follow the red star. He could hold onto that thought.

θɹi taɪmz ðeɪ hæd tə bæktʃɹæk fɹəm ə stʃɹit blɑk fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd baɪ ə hɪl ə stoʊn ən bɹɪk ðə hɔɹsəz kəd nɛvɝ əv kɹɔst. ɹænd kəd hɪɹ ði ʌðɝz bɹiðɪŋ, ʃɔɹɾ ən ʃɑɹp, dʒʌst ʃaɪ ʌv pænɪk. hi ɡɹɪɾɪd ɪz tiθ tə stɑp ɪz oʊn pæntɪŋ. juv tə ət lis meɪk əm θɪŋk jəɹ nɑɾ əfɹeɪd. jəɹ duɪŋ ə ɡʊd dʒɑb, wʊl-hɛd! jəl ɡɛɾ ɛvɹibɑɾi aʊt seɪfli.

Three times they had to backtrack from a street blocked from side to side by a hill of stone and brick the horses could never have crossed. Rand could hear the others breathing, short and sharp, just shy of panic. He gritted his teeth to stop his own panting. You have to at least make them think you're not afraid. You're doing a good job, wool-head! You'll get everybody out safely.

ðeɪ ɹaʊndəd ðə nɛks kɔɹnɝ. ə wɔl ə fɑɡ beɪðd ðə bɹoʊkən peɪvmənt wɪð ə laɪɾ əz bɹaɪɾ əz ə fʊl mun. stʃɹimɝz əz θɪk əz ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz bɹoʊk ɔf təwɔɹd ðɛm. noʊbɑdi weɪɾəd. wilɪŋ, ðeɪ ɡæləpt əweɪ ɪn ə taɪt nɑt wɪð noʊ hid fəɹ ðə klæɾɝ ə hʊvz ðeɪ ɹeɪzd.

They rounded the next corner. A wall of fog bathed the broken pavement with a light as bright as a full moon. Streamers as thick as their horses broke off toward them. Nobody waited. Wheeling, they galloped away in a tight knot with no heed for the clatter of hooves they raised.

tu tʃɹɑləks stɛpt ɪndə ðə stʃɹit bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, nɑt tɛn spænz əweɪ.

Two Trollocs stepped into the street before them, not ten spans away.

fəɹ ən ɪnstən ðə hjumənz ən ðə tʃɹɑləks dʒʌst stɛɹɾ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ, itʃ mɔɹ sɝpɹaɪz ðən ði ʌðɝ. ənʌðɝ pɛɹ ə tʃɹɑləks əpɪɹd, ən ənʌðɝ, ən ənʌðɝ, kəlaɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə wʌnz ɪn fɹʌnt, foʊldɪŋ ɪndə ə ʃɑk mæs ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðə hjumənz. oʊnli fəɹ ən ɪnstən dɪd ðeɪ ɹɪmeɪn fɹoʊzən, ðoʊ. ɡʌɾɝəl haʊlz ɛkoʊd fɹəm ðə bɪldɪŋz, ən ðə tʃɹɑləks baʊndəd fɔɹwɝd. ðə hjumənz skæɾɝd laɪk kweɪl.

For an instant the humans and the Trollocs just stared at one another, each more surprised than the other. Another pair of Trollocs appeared, and another, and another, colliding with the ones in front, folding into a shocked mass at the sight of the humans. Only for an instant did they remain frozen, though. Guttural howls echoed from the buildings, and the Trollocs bounded forward. The humans scattered like quail.

ɹændz ɡɹeɪ ɹitʃt fʊl ɡæləp ɪn θɹi stʃɹaɪdz. "ðɪs weɪ!" hi ʃaʊɾəd, bʌɾ i hɝd ðə seɪm kɹaɪ fɹəm faɪv θɹoʊts. ə heɪsti ɡlæns oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ʃoʊɾ ɪm ɪz kəmpænjənz dɪsəpɪɹɪŋ ɪn əz mɛni dɝɛkʃənz, tʃɹɑləks pɝsuɪŋ əm ɔl.

Rand's gray reached full gallop in three strides. "This way!" he shouted, but he heard the same cry from five throats. A hasty glance over his shoulder showed him his companions disappearing in as many directions, Trollocs pursuing them all.

θɹi tʃɹɑləks ɹæn əɾ ɪz oʊn hilz, kætʃpoʊlz weɪvɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. hɪz skɪn kɹɔld əz i ɹilaɪz ðeɪ wɝ mætʃɪŋ klaʊd stʃɹaɪd fəɹ stʃɹaɪd. hi dʒɹɑp loʊ ɑn klaʊdz nɛk ən ɝdʒ ðə ɡɹeɪ ɑn, tʃeɪs baɪ θɪk kɹaɪz.

Three Trollocs ran at his own heels, catchpoles waving in the air. His skin crawled as he realized they were matching Cloud stride for stride. He dropped low on Cloud's neck and urged the gray on, chased by thick cries.

ðə stʃɹit nɛɹoʊɾ əhɛd, bɹoʊkən-tɑp bɪldɪŋz linɪŋ aʊt dʒɹʌŋkənli. sloʊli ði ɛmpti wɪndoʊz fɪld wɪð ə sɪlvɝi ɡloʊ, ə dɛns mɪs bʌlʒɪŋ aʊtwɝd. mɑʃəɾɝ.

The street narrowed ahead, broken-topped buildings leaning out drunkenly. Slowly the empty windows filled with a silvery glow, a dense mist bulging outward. Mashadar.

ɹænd ɹɪskt ə ɡlæns oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ðə tʃɹɑləks stɪl ɹæn lɛs ðən fɪfti peɪsɪz bæk; ðə laɪt fɹəm ðə fɑɡ wɑz ɪnʌf tə si ðɛm klɪɹli. eɪ feɪd ɹoʊd bɪhaɪn əm naʊ, ən ðeɪ sim tə fli ðə hæfmən əz mʌtʃ əz tə pɝsu ɹænd. əhɛɾ ə ɹænd, hæf ə dʌzən ɡɹeɪ tɛnʒɹəlz weɪvɝd fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊz, ə dʌzən, filɪŋ ði ɛɹ. klaʊd tɔst ɪz hɛɾ ən skɹimd, bʌt ɹænd dʌɡ hɪz hilz ɪn bɹuɾəli, ən ðə hɔɹs lʌnʒd fɔɹwɝd waɪldli.

Rand risked a glance over his shoulder. The Trollocs still ran less than fifty paces back; the light from the fog was enough to see them clearly. A Fade rode behind them now, and they seemed to flee the Halfman as much as to pursue Rand. Ahead of Rand, half a dozen gray tendrils wavered from the windows, a dozen, feeling the air. Cloud tossed his head and screamed, but Rand dug his heels in brutally, and the horse lunged forward wildly.

ðə tɛnʒɹəlz stɪfən əz ɹænd ɡæləp bɪtwin ðɛm, bʌɾ i kɹaʊtʃt loʊ ɑn klaʊdz bæk ən ɹəfjuz tə lʊk ət ðɛm. ðə weɪ bɪɑnd wɑz klɪɹ. ɪf wʌn ə ðɛm tʌtʃəz mi. . . . laɪt! hi buɾɪd klaʊd hɑɹɾɝ, ən ðə hɔɹs lɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ɪndə ðə wɛlkəm ʃædoʊz. wɪð klaʊd stɪl ɹʌnɪŋ, hi lʊk bæk əz sun əz ðə ɡloʊ ʌv mɑʃəɾɝ bɪɡæn tə lɛsən.

The tendrils stiffened as Rand galloped between them, but he crouched low on Cloud's back and refused to look at them. The way beyond was clear. If one of them touches me. . . . Light! He booted Cloud harder, and the horse leaped forward into the welcome shadows. With Cloud still running, he looked back as soon as the glow of Mashadar began to lessen.

ðə weɪvɪŋ ɡɹeɪ tɛntəkəlz ə mɑʃəɾɝ blɑk hæf ðə stʃɹit, ən ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ bɔkɪŋ, bʌt ðə feɪd snætʃt ə wɪp fɹəm ɪts sæɾəlboʊ, kɹækɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə hɛdz ə ðə tʃɹɑləks wɪð ə saʊn laɪk ə laɪtnɪŋ boʊlt, pɑpɪŋ spɑɹks ɪn ði ɛɹ. kɹaʊtʃɪŋ, ðə tʃɹɑləks lɝtʃt æftɝ ɹænd. ðə hæfmən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, blæk kaʊl stʌɾiɪŋ mɑʃəɾɝz ɹitʃɪŋ ɑɹmz, bɪfɔɹ ɪt, tu, spɝd fɔɹwɝd.

The waving gray tentacles of Mashadar blocked half the street, and the Trollocs were balking, but the Fade snatched a whip from its saddlebow, cracking it over the heads of the Trollocs with a sound like a lightning bolt, popping sparks in the air. Crouching, the Trollocs lurched after Rand. The Halfman hesitated, black cowl studying Mashadar's reaching arms, before it, too, spurred forward.

ðə θɪkənɪŋ tɛntəkəlz ə fɑɡ swʌŋ ənsɝteɪnli fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən stʃɹʌk laɪk vaɪpɝz. ət lis tu lætʃt tə itʃ tʃɹɑlɑk, beɪðɪŋ əm ɪn ɡɹeɪ laɪt; mʌzəl hɛdz wɛn bæk tə skɹim, bʌt fɑɡ ɹoʊld oʊvɝ oʊpən maʊðz, ən ɪn, iɾɪŋ ðə haʊlz. fɔɹ lɛɡ-θɪk tɛntəkəlz wɪpt ɝaʊn ðə feɪd, ən ðə hæfmən ən ɪts blæk hɔɹs twɪtʃt əz ɪf dænsɪŋ, tɪl ðə kaʊl fɛl bæk, bɛɹɪŋ ðət peɪl, aɪləs feɪs. ðə feɪd ʃɹikt.

The thickening tentacles of fog swung uncertainly for a moment, then struck like vipers. At least two latched to each Trolloc, bathing them in gray light; muzzled heads went back to scream, but fog rolled over open mouths, and in, eating the howls. Four leg-thick tentacles whipped around the Fade, and the Halfman and its black horse twitched as if dancing, till the cowl fell back, baring that pale, eyeless face. The Fade shrieked.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saʊn fɹəm ðət kɹaɪ, ɛni mɔɹ ðən fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑləks, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ keɪm θɹu, ə pɪɹsɪŋ waɪn dʒʌs bɪɑn hɪɹɪŋ, laɪk ɔl ðə hɔɹnəts ɪn ðə wɝld, dɪɡɪŋ ɪndə ɹændz ɪɹz wɪð ɔl ðə fɪɹ ðət kəɾ ɪɡzɪst. klaʊd kənvʌlsd, əz ɪf hi, tu, hɝd, ən ɹæn hɑɹɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ. ɹænd hʌŋ ɑn, pæntɪŋ, hɪz θɹoʊɾ əz dʒɹaɪ əz sænd.

There was no sound from that cry, any more than from the Trollocs, but something came through, a piercing whine just beyond hearing, like all the hornets in the world, digging into Rand's ears with all the fear that could exist. Cloud convulsed, as if he, too, heard, and ran harder than ever. Rand hung on, panting, his throat as dry as sand.

æftɝ ə taɪm i ɹilaɪzd i kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hɪɹ ðə saɪlənt ʃɹik ə ðə feɪd daɪɪŋ, ən sʌɾənli ðə klæɾɝ ə hɪz ɡæləp simd əz laʊɾ əz ʃaʊts. hi ɹeɪn klaʊd hɑɹd, stɑpɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ə dʒæɡd wɔl, ɹaɪt wɛɹ tu stʃɹits mɛt. ə neɪmləs mɑnjəmən ɹɪɹɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs bɪfɔɹ hɪm.

After a time he realized he could no longer hear the silent shriek of the Fade dying, and suddenly the clatter of his gallop seemed as loud as shouts. He reined Cloud hard, stopping beside a jagged wall, right where two streets met. A nameless monument reared in the darkness before him.

slʌmpt ɪn ðə sæɾəl, hi lɪsənd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə hɪɹ ɪksɛp ðə blʌd paʊndɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz. koʊl swɛt biɾɪd ɑn ɪz feɪs, ən i ʃɪvɝɾ əz ðə wɪn fleɪld ɪz kloʊk.

Slumped in the saddle, he listened, but there was nothing to hear except the blood pounding in his ears. Cold sweat beaded on his face, and he shivered as the wind flailed his cloak.

faɪnəli hi stʃɹeɪɾənd. stɑɹz spæŋɡəl ðə skaɪ wɛɹ ðə klaʊdz dɪd nɑt haɪd ðɛm, bʌt ðə ɹɛd stɑɹ loʊ ɪn ði ist wɑz izi tə mɑɹk. ɪz ɛnibəɾi ɛls əlaɪv tə si ɪt? wɝ ðeɪ fɹi, əɹ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑləks' hænz? ɛɡwin, laɪt blaɪn mi, waɪ dɪdn jə fɑloʊ mi? ɪf ðeɪ wɝ əlaɪv ən fɹi, ðeɪ wəd bi fɑloʊɪŋ ðət stɑɹ. ɪf nɑt. . . . ðə ɹuənz wɝ væst; hi kəd sɝtʃ fəɹ deɪz wɪθaʊt faɪndɪŋ ɛniwʌn, ɪf i kəd kip əweɪ fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑləks. ən ðə feɪdz, ən mɔɹɾɪθ, ən mɑʃəɾɝ. ɹɪlʌktənli hi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə meɪk fəɹ ðə ɹɪvɝ.

Finally he straightened. Stars spangled the sky where the clouds did not hide them, but the red star low in the east was easy to mark. Is anybody else alive to see it? Were they free, or in the Trollocs' hands? Egwene, Light blind me, why didn't you follow me? If they were alive and free, they would be following that star. If not. . . . The ruins were vast; he could search for days without finding anyone, if he could keep away from the Trollocs. And the Fades, and Mordeth, and Mashadar. Reluctantly he decided to make for the river.

hi ɡæðɝd ðə ɹeɪnz. ɑn ðə kɹɔsɪŋ stʃɹit, wʌn stoʊn fɛl əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ wɪð ə ʃɑɹp klɪk. hi fɹoʊz, nɑɾ ivən bɹiðɪŋ. hi wɑz hɪɾən ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz, wʌn stɛp fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ. fɹæntəkəli hi θɔɾ ə bækɪŋ ʌp. wʌt wɑz bɪhaɪn hɪm? wʌt wəd meɪk ə nɔɪz ən ɡɪv ɪm əweɪ? hi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ən i wɑz əfɹeɪd tə teɪk ɪz aɪz fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə ðə bɪldɪŋ.

He gathered the reins. On the crossing street, one stone fell against another with a sharp click. He froze, not even breathing. He was hidden in the shadows, one step from the corner. Frantically he thought of backing up. What was behind him? What would make a noise and give him away? He could not remember, and he was afraid to take his eyes from the corner of the building.

dɑɹknəs bʌlkt ət ðət kɔɹnɝ, wɪð ðə lɔŋɡɝ dɑɹknəs ʌv ə ʃæf stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. kætʃpoʊl! ivən əz ðə θɔt flæʃt ɪndə ɹændz hɛd, hi dʌɡ hɪz hilz ɪndə klaʊdz ɹɪbz ən ɪz sɔɹd flu fɹəm ðə skæbɝd; ə wɝdləs ʃaʊɾ əkʌmpəniɾ ɪz tʃɑɹdʒ, ən i swʌŋ ðə sɔɹd wɪð ɔl ə hɪz maɪt. oʊnli ə dɛspɹɪɾ ɛfɝt stɑp ðə bleɪd ʃɔɹt. wɪð ə jɛlp mæt tʌmbəl bæk, hæf fɔlɪŋ ɔf ɪz hɔɹs ən nɪɹli dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪz baʊ.

Darkness bulked at that corner, with the longer darkness of a shaft sticking out of it. Catchpole! Even as the thought flashed into Rand's head, he dug his heels into Cloud's ribs and his sword flew from the scabbard; a wordless shout accompanied his charge, and he swung the sword with all of his might. Only a desperate effort stopped the blade short. With a yelp Mat tumbled back, half falling off his horse and nearly dropping his bow.

ɹænd dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ ən loʊɝɾ ɪz sɔɹd. hɪz ɑɹm ʃʊk. "hæv jə sin ɛnibəɾi ɛls?" hi mænədʒd.

Rand drew a deep breath and lowered his sword. His arm shook. "Have you seen anybody else?" he managed.

mæt swɑloʊd hɑɹd bɪfɔɹ pʊlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɔkwɝdli bæk ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl. "aɪ . . . aɪ. . . . dʒʌs tʃɹɑləks." hi pʊɾ ə hæn tə hɪz θɹoʊt, ən lɪkt ɪz lɪps. "dʒʌs tʃɹɑləks. ju?"

Mat swallowed hard before pulling himself awkwardly back into his saddle. "I . . . I. . . . Just Trollocs." He put a hand to his throat, and licked his lips. "Just Trollocs. You?"

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðeɪ mʌs bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹitʃ ðə ɹɪvɝ. wi bɛɾɝ də ðə seɪm." mæt nɑɾəd saɪlənli, stɪl filɪŋ ɪz θɹoʊt, ən ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðə ɹɛd stɑɹ.

Rand shook his head. "They must be trying to reach the river. We better do the same." Mat nodded silently, still feeling his throat, and they started toward the red star.

bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ hæd kʌvɝɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd spænz ðə kinɪŋ kɹaɪ ʌv ə tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹn ɹoʊz bɪhaɪn əm ɪn ðə dɛpθs ə ðə sɪɾi. ənʌðɝ ænsɝd, fɹəm aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz.

Before they had covered a hundred spans the keening cry of a Trolloc horn rose behind them in the depths of the city. Another answered, from outside the walls.

ɹænd ʃɪvɝd, bʌɾ i kɛp tə hɪz sloʊ peɪs, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə dɑɹkəs pleɪsəz ən əvɔɪɾɪŋ əm wən i kʊd. æftɝ wʌn dʒɝk əɾ ɪz ɹeɪnz əz ɪf i maɪt ɡæləp ɔf, mæt dɪd ðə seɪm. niðɝ hɔɹn saʊndəɾ əɡɛn, ən ɪt wɑz ɪn saɪləns ðət ðeɪ keɪm tə ən oʊpənɪŋ ɪn ðə vaɪn-ʃɹaʊɾɪd wɔl wɛɹ ə ɡeɪt hæd wʌns bɪn. oʊnli ðə taʊɝz ɹɪmeɪnd, stændɪŋ bɹoʊkən-tɑpt əɡɛns ðə blæk skaɪ.

Rand shivered, but he kept to his slow pace, watching the darkest places and avoiding them when he could. After one jerk at his reins as if he might gallop off, Mat did the same. Neither horn sounded again, and it was in silence that they came to an opening in the vine-shrouded wall where a gate had once been. Only the towers remained, standing broken-topped against the black sky.

mæt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ət ðə ɡeɪtweɪ, bʌt ɹænd sɛd sɔfli, "ɪz ɪɾ ɛni seɪfɝ ɪn hɪɹ ðən aʊt ðɛɹ?" hi dɪd nɑt sloʊ ðə ɡɹeɪ, ən æftɝ ə moʊmən mæt fɑloʊɾ ɪm aʊɾ ə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lʊk ɛvɹi weɪ ət wʌns. ɹænd lɛɾ aʊɾ ə sloʊ bɹɛθ; hɪz maʊθ wɑz dʒɹaɪ. wɝ gɑnə meɪk ɪt. laɪt, wɝ gɑnə meɪk ɪt!

Mat hesitated at the gateway, but Rand said softly, "Is it any safer in here than out there?" He did not slow the gray, and after a moment Mat followed him out of Shadar Logoth, trying to look every way at once. Rand let out a slow breath; his mouth was dry. We're going to make it. Light, we're going to make it!

ðə wɔlz vænɪʃt bɪhaɪnd, swɑloʊd baɪ ðə naɪɾ ən ðə fɔɹəst. lɪsnɪŋ fəɹ ðə slaɪɾəst saʊnd, ɹænd kɛp ðə ɹɛd stɑɹ dɛɾ əhɛd.

The walls vanished behind, swallowed by the night and the forest. Listening for the slightest sound, Rand kept the red star dead ahead.

sʌɾənli tɑm ɡæləp baɪ fɹəm bɪhaɪnd, sloʊɪŋ oʊnli lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ʃaʊt, "ɹaɪd, jə fulz!" ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ hʌntɪŋ kɹaɪz ən kɹæʃɪz ɪn ðə bɹʌʃ bɪhaɪn ɪm ənaʊns ðə pɹɛzəns ə tʃɹɑləks ɑn ɪz tʃɹeɪl.

Suddenly Thom galloped by from behind, slowing only long enough to shout, "Ride, you fools!" A moment later hunting cries and crashes in the brush behind him announced the presence of Trollocs on his trail.

ɹænd dʌɡ ɪn ɪz hilz, ən klaʊd spɹæŋ æftɝ ðə ɡlimənz ɡɛldɪŋ. wʌt hæpənz wən wi ɡɛt tə ðə ɹɪvɝ wɪθaʊt mɔɪɹeɪn? laɪt, ɛɡwin!

Rand dug in his heels, and Cloud sprang after the gleeman's gelding. What happens when we get to the river without Moiraine? Light, Egwene!

pɛɹɪn sæɾ ɪz hɔɹs ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz, wɑtʃɪŋ ði oʊpən ɡeɪtweɪ, səm lɪɾəl dɪstəns ɔf jɛt, ən æbsənli ɹæn ɪz θʌm əlɔŋ ðə bleɪɾ ə hɪz æks. ɪt sim tə bi ə klɪɹ weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹuən sɪɾi, bʌɾ i hæd sæt ðəɹ fəɹ faɪv mɪnəts stʌɾiɪŋ ɪt. ðə wɪn tɔst ɪz ʃæɡi kɝlz ən tʃɹaɪd tə kæɹi hɪz kloʊk əweɪ, bʌɾ i pʊl ðə kloʊk bæk ɝaʊn ɪm wɪθaʊt ɹɪli noʊɾɪsɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ.

Perrin sat his horse in the shadows, watching the open gateway, some little distance off yet, and absently ran his thumb along the blade of his axe. It seemed to be a clear way out of the ruined city, but he had sat there for five minutes studying it. The wind tossed his shaggy curls and tried to carry his cloak away, but he pulled the cloak back around him without really noticing what he was doing.

hi nu ðət mæt, ən ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ɪn ɛmənz fild, kənsɪɾɝd ɪm sloʊ ʌv θɔt. ɪt wɑz pɑɹtli kəz i wɑz bɪɡ ən juʒəwəli muv kɛɹfəli - hi hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn əfɹeɪɾ i maɪɾ æksədɛntəli bɹeɪk sʌmθɪŋ əɹ hɝt sʌmbɑɾi, sɪns i wɑz soʊ mʌtʃ bɪɡɝ ðən ðə bɔɪz i ɡɹu ʌp wɪð - bʌɾ i ɹɪli dɪd pɹəfɝ tə θɪŋk θɪŋz ɔl ðə weɪ θɹu ɪf i kʊd. kwɪk θɪŋkɪŋ, kɛɹləs θɪŋkɪŋ, hæd pʊt mæt ɪndə hɑt wɔɾɝ wʌn taɪm æftɝ ənʌðɝ, ən mæts kwɪk θɪŋkɪŋ juʒəwəli mænədʒ tə ɡɛt ɹænd, əɹ hɪm, əɹ boʊθ, ɪn ðə kʊkpɑɾ əlɔŋsaɪd mæt, tu.

He knew that Mat, and almost everyone else in Emond's Field, considered him slow of thought. It was partly because he was big and usually moved carefully - he had always been afraid he might accidentally break something or hurt somebody, since he was so much bigger than the boys he grew up with - but he really did prefer to think things all the way through if he could. Quick thinking, careless thinking, had put Mat into hot water one time after another, and Mat's quick thinking usually managed to get Rand, or him, or both, in the cookpot alongside Mat, too.

hɪz θɹoʊt taɪɾənd. laɪt, doʊn θɪŋk əbaʊt biɪŋ ɪn ə kʊkpɑt. hi tʃɹaɪd tə ɔɹɾɝ ɪz θɔts əɡɛn. kɛɹfəl θɔt wɑz ðə weɪ.

His throat tightened. Light, don't think about being in a cookpot. He tried to order his thoughts again. Careful thought was the way.

ðəɹ hæd bɪn səm sɔɹɾ ə skwɛɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ɡeɪt wʌns, wɪð ə hjudʒ faʊntən ɪn ɪts mɪɾəl. pɑɹɾ ə ðə faʊntən wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, ə klʌstɝ ə bɹoʊkən stætʃuz stændɪŋ ɪn ə bɪɡ, ɹaʊn beɪsən, ən soʊ wɑz ði oʊpən speɪs ɝaʊn ɪt. tə ɹitʃ ðə ɡeɪɾ i wəɾ əv tə ɹaɪd nɪɹli ə hʌnʒɹəd spænz wɪð oʊnli ðə naɪt tə ʃild ɪm fɹəm sɝtʃɪŋ aɪz. ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə plɛzən θɔt, iðɝ. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðoʊz ənsin wɑtʃɝz tu wɛl.

There had been some sort of square in front of the gate once, with a huge fountain in its middle. Part of the fountain was still there, a cluster of broken statues standing in a big, round basin, and so was the open space around it. To reach the gate he would have to ride nearly a hundred spans with only the night to shield him from searching eyes. That was not a pleasant thought, either. He remembered those unseen watchers too well.

hi kənsɪɾɝd ðə hɔɹnz i hæd hɝɾ ɪn ðə sɪɾi ə lɪɾəl waɪl ɝliɝ. hi hæɾ ɔlmoʊs tɝn bæk, θɪŋkɪŋ səm ə ði ʌðɝz maɪɾ əv bɪn teɪkən, bɪfɔɹ ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðəɾ i kəd nɑt də ɛniθɪŋ əloʊn ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn kæptʃɝd. nɑɾ əɡɛnst - wʌd læn seɪ - ə hʌnʒɹəd tʃɹɑləks ən fɔɹ feɪdz. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛd ɡɛt tə ðə ɹɪvɝ.

He considered the horns he had heard in the city a little while earlier. He had almost turned back, thinking some of the others might have been taken, before realizing that he could not do anything alone if they had been captured. Not against - what did Lan say - a hundred Trollocs and four Fades. Moiraine Sedai said get to the river.

hi wɛn bæk tə kənsɪɾɝeɪʃən ə ðə ɡeɪt. kɛɹfəl θɔt hæd nɑt ɡɪvən ɪm mʌtʃ, bʌɾ i hæd meɪɾ ɪz dɪsɪʒən. hi ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə dipɝ ʃædoʊ ɪndə ðə lɛsɝ dɑɹknəs.

He went back to consideration of the gate. Careful thought had not given him much, but he had made his decision. He rode out of the deeper shadow into the lesser darkness.

əz i dɪd, ənʌðɝ hɔɹs əpɪɹd fɹəm ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə skwɛɹ ən stɑpt. hi stɑpt, tu, ən fɛl fəɹ ɪz æks; ɪt ɡeɪv ɪm noʊ ɡɹeɪt sɛns ə kʌmfɝt. ɪf ðət dɑɹk ʃeɪp wɑz ə feɪd. . . .

As he did, another horse appeared from the far side of the square and stopped. He stopped, too, and felt for his axe; it gave him no great sense of comfort. If that dark shape was a Fade. . . .

"ɹænd?" keɪm ə sɑft, hɛzɪɾənt kɔl.

"Rand?" came a soft, hesitant call.

hi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ, ɹɪliv bɹɛθ. "ɪts pɛɹɪn, ɛɡwin," hi kɔl bæk, dʒʌst əz sɔfli. ɪt stɪl saʊndəd tu laʊɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs.

He let out a long, relieved breath. "It's Perrin, Egwene," he called back, just as softly. It still sounded too loud in the darkness.

ðə hɔɹsəz keɪm təɡɛðɝ nɪɹ ðə faʊntən.

The horses came together near the fountain.

"hæv jə sin ɛnibəɾi ɛls?" ðeɪ boʊθ æskt ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ən boʊθ ænsɝd baɪ ʃeɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz.

"Have you seen anybody else?" they both asked at the same time, and both answered by shaking their heads.

"ðeɪl bi ɔl ɹaɪt," ɛɡwin mʌɾɝd, pæɾɪŋ bɛləz nɛk. "woʊn ðeɪ?"

"They'll be all right," Egwene muttered, patting Bela's neck. "Won't they?"

"mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ ən læn wɪl lʊk æftɝ ðɛm," pɛɹɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "ðeɪ wɪl lʊk æftɝ ɔl ʌv əs wʌns wi ɡɛt tə ðə ɹɪvɝ." hi hoʊpt ɪt wɑz soʊ.

"Moiraine Sedai and Lan will look after them," Perrin replied. "They will look after all of us once we get to the river." He hoped it was so.

hi fɛlt ə ɡɹeɪt ɹɪlif wʌns ðeɪ wɝ bɪɑn ðə ɡeɪt, ivən ɪf ðəɹ wɝ tʃɹɑləks ɪn ðə fɔɹəst. əɹ feɪdz. hi stɑp ðət laɪn ə θɔt. ðə bɛɹ bɹæntʃəz wɝ nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə kip ɪm fɹəm ɡaɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹɛd stɑɹ, ən ðeɪ wɝ bɪɑn mɔɹɾɪθs ɹitʃ naʊ. ðət wʌn hæd fɹaɪɾənd ɪm wɝs ðən ðə tʃɹɑləks ɛvɝ hæd.

He felt a great relief once they were beyond the gate, even if there were Trollocs in the forest. Or Fades. He stopped that line of thought. The bare branches were not enough to keep him from guiding on the red star, and they were beyond Mordeth's reach now. That one had frightened him worse than the Trollocs ever had.

sun ðeɪ wəd ɹitʃ ðə ɹɪvɝ ən mit mɔɪɹeɪn, ən ʃi wəd pʊɾ əm bɪɑn ðə tʃɹɑləks' ɹitʃ əz wɛl. hi bɪlivd ɪt kəz i niɾəd tə bɪliv. ðə wɪn skɹeɪp bɹæntʃəz təɡɛðɝ ən ɹʌsəl ðə livz ən niɾəlz ɑn ði ɛvɝɡɹinz. ə naɪthɔks loʊnli kɹaɪ dʒɹɪftəɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk, ən i ən ɛɡwin muv ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz kloʊsɝ təɡɛðɝ əz ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ hʌɾəlɪŋ fəɹ wɔɹmθ. ðeɪ wɝ vɛɹi mʌtʃ əloʊn.

Soon they would reach the river and meet Moiraine, and she would put them beyond the Trollocs' reach as well. He believed it because he needed to believe. The wind scraped branches together and rustled the leaves and needles on the evergreens. A nighthawk's lonely cry drifted in the dark, and he and Egwene moved their horses closer together as though they were huddling for warmth. They were very much alone.

eɪ tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹn saʊndəd sʌmwɛɹ bɪhaɪn ðɛm, kwɪk, weɪlɪŋ blæsts, ɝdʒɪŋ ðə hʌntɝz tə hɝi, hɝi. ðən θɪk, hæf-hjumən haʊlz ɹoʊz ɑn ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪl, spɝɾ ɑn baɪ ðə hɔɹn. haʊlz ðət ɡɹu ʃɑɹpɝ əz ðeɪ kɑt ðə hjumən sɛnt.

A Trolloc horn sounded somewhere behind them, quick, wailing blasts, urging the hunters to hurry, hurry. Then thick, half-human howls rose on their trail, spurred on by the horn. Howls that grew sharper as they caught the human scent.

pɛɹɪn pʊɾ ɪz hɔɹs tə ə ɡæləp, ʃaʊɾɪŋ, "kʌm ɑn!" ɛɡwin keɪm, boʊθ ə ðɛm buɾɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, hidləs ə nɔɪz, hidləs ə ðə bɹæntʃəz ðət slæpt ət ðɛm.

Perrin put his horse to a gallop, shouting, "Come on!" Egwene came, both of them booting their horses, heedless of noise, heedless of the branches that slapped at them.

əz ðeɪ ɹeɪs θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, ɡaɪɾəd əz mʌtʃ baɪ ɪnstɪŋkt əz baɪ ðə dɪm munlaɪt, bɛlə fɛl bɪhaɪnd. pɛɹɪn lʊk bæk. ɛɡwin kɪk ðə mɛɹ ən fleɪld əɹ wɪð ðə ɹeɪnz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz duɪŋ noʊ ɡʊd. baɪ ðɛɹ saʊnz, ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ kʌmɪŋ kloʊsɝ. hi dʒɹu ɪn ɪnʌf nɑt tə liv əɹ bɪhaɪnd.

As they raced through the trees, guided as much by instinct as by the dim moonlight, Bela fell behind. Perrin looked back. Egwene kicked the mare and flailed her with the reins, but it was doing no good. By their sounds, the Trollocs were coming closer. He drew in enough not to leave her behind.

"hɝi!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. hi kəd meɪk aʊt ðə tʃɹɑləks naʊ, hjudʒ dɑɹk ʃeɪps baʊndɪŋ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz, bɛloʊɪŋ ən snɑɹlɪŋ tə tʃɪl ðə blʌd. hi ɡɹɪp ðə hæft ə hɪz æks, hæŋɪŋ əɾ ɪz bɛlt, əntɪl ɪz nʌkəlz hɝt. "hɝi, ɛɡwin! hɝi!"

"Hurry!" he shouted. He could make out the Trollocs now, huge dark shapes bounding through the trees, bellowing and snarling to chill the blood. He gripped the haft of his axe, hanging at his belt, until his knuckles hurt. "Hurry, Egwene! Hurry!"

sʌɾənli hɪz hɔɹs skɹimd, ən i wɑz fɔlɪŋ, tʌmbəlɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl əz ðə hɔɹs dʒɹɑpt əweɪ bɪniθ hɪm. hi flʌŋ aʊɾ ɪz hænz tə bɹeɪs hɪmsɛlf ən splæʃt hɛdfɝst ɪndə aɪsi wɔɾɝ. hi hæd ɹɪɾən ɹaɪɾ ɔf ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə ʃɪɹ blʌf ɪndə ði ɑɹɪnɛl.

Suddenly his horse screamed, and he was falling, tumbling out of the saddle as the horse dropped away beneath him. He flung out his hands to brace himself and splashed headfirst into icy water. He had ridden right off the edge of a sheer bluff into the Arinelle.

ðə ʃɑk ə fɹizɪŋ wɔɾɝ ɹɪpt ə ɡæsp fɹəm hɪm, ən i swɑloʊd mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl bɪfɔɹ i mænədʒ tə faɪɾ ɪz weɪ tə ðə sɝfəs. hi fɛl mɔɹ ðən hɝɾ ənʌðɝ splæʃ, ən θɔt ðəɾ ɛɡwin mʌst əv kʌm ɹaɪɾ æftɝ hɪm. pæntɪŋ ən bloʊɪŋ, hi tʃɹɛɾɪd wɔɾɝ. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ izi tə kip əfloʊt; hɪz koʊɾ ən kloʊk wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi sɑɾən, ən ɪz buts hæd fɪld. hi lʊkt ɝaʊn fəɹ ɛɡwin, bʌt sɔ oʊnli ðə ɡlɪn ə munlaɪɾ ɑn ðə blæk wɔɾɝ, ɹʌfəl baɪ ðə wɪnd.

The shock of freezing water ripped a gasp from him, and he swallowed more than a little before he managed to fight his way to the surface. He felt more than heard another splash, and thought that Egwene must have come right after him. Panting and blowing, he treaded water. It was not easy to keep afloat; his coat and cloak were already sodden, and his boots had filled. He looked around for Egwene, but saw only the glint of moonlight on the black water, ruffled by the wind.

"ɛɡwin? ɛɡwin!"

"Egwene? Egwene!"

ə spɪɹ flæʃt ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz aɪz ən θɹu wɔɾɝ ɪn ɪz feɪs. ʌðɝz splæʃt ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ ɝaʊn hɪm, tu. ɡʌɾɝəl vɔɪsəz ɹeɪzd ɪn ɑɹɡjəmən ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk, ən ðə tʃɹɑlɑk spɪɹz stɑp kʌmɪŋ, bʌɾ i ɡeɪv ʌp ɑn kɔlɪŋ fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ.

A spear flashed right in front of his eyes and threw water in his face. Others splashed into the river around him, too. Guttural voices raised in argument on the riverbank, and the Trolloc spears stopped coming, but he gave up on calling for the time being.

ðə kɝənt wɑʃt ɪm daʊnɹɪvɝ, bʌt ðə θɪk ʃaʊts ən snɑɹlz fɑloʊɾ əlɔŋ ðə bæŋk, kipɪŋ peɪs. ənduɪŋ ɪz kloʊk, hi lɛt ðə ɹɪvɝ teɪk ɪt. ə lɪɾəl lɛs weɪt tə dʒɹæɡ hɪm daʊn. dɔɡədli, hi sɛɾ aʊt swɪmɪŋ fəɹ ðə fɑɹ bæŋk. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ tʃɹɑləks ðɛɹ. hi hoʊpt.

The current washed him downriver, but the thick shouts and snarls followed along the bank, keeping pace. Undoing his cloak, he let the river take it. A little less weight to drag him down. Doggedly, he set out swimming for the far bank. There were no Trollocs there. He hoped.

hi swæm ðə weɪ ðeɪ dɪd bæk hoʊm, ɪn ðə pɑnz ɪn ðə wɔɾɝwʊd, stʃɹoʊkɪŋ wɪð boʊθ hænz, kɪkɪŋ wɪð boʊθ fit, kipɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə wɔɾɝ. ət list, hi tʃɹaɪd tə kip ɪz hɛɾ aʊɾ ə ðə wɔɾɝ; ɪt wɑz nɑɾ izi. ivən wɪθaʊt ðə kloʊk, hɪz koʊɾ ən buts itʃ sim tə weɪ əz mʌtʃ əz i dɪd. ən ði æks dʒɹæɡd əɾ ɪz weɪst, θɹɛɾənɪŋ tə ɹoʊl ɪm oʊvɝ ɪf ɪt dɪd nɑt pʊl ɪm ʌndɝ. hi θɔɾ əbaʊt lɛɾɪŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ əv ðæt, tu; hi θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt mɔɹ ðən wʌns. ɪt wəd bi izi, mʌtʃ iziɝ ðən stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz buts, fəɹ ɪnstəns. bʌɾ ɛvɹi taɪm i θɔɾ ʌv ɪt, hi θɔɾ ə kɹɔlɪŋ aʊɾ ɑn ðə fɑɹ bæŋk tə faɪn tʃɹɑləks weɪɾɪŋ. ði æks wəd nɑt də hɪm mʌtʃ ɡʊɾ əɡɛns hæf ə dʌzən tʃɹɑləks - əɹ ivən əɡɛnst wʌn, meɪbi - bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən ɪz bɛɹ hænz.

He swam the way they did back home, in the ponds in the Waterwood, stroking with both hands, kicking with both feet, keeping his head out of the water. At least, he tried to keep his head out of the water; it was not easy. Even without the cloak, his coat and boots each seemed to weigh as much as he did.
