And the axe dragged at his waist, threatening to roll him over if it did not pull him under. He thought about letting the river have that, too; he thought about it more than once. It would be easy, much easier than struggling out of his boots, for instance. But every time he thought of it, he thought of crawling out on the far bank to find Trollocs waiting. The axe would not do him much good against half a dozen Trollocs - or even against one, maybe - but it was better than his bare hands.

æftɝ ə waɪl i wɑz nɑɾ ivən sɝɾən i wəd bi eɪbəl tə lɪf ði æks ɪf tʃɹɑləks wɝ ðɛɹ. hɪz ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz bɪkeɪm lɛɾən; ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt tə muv ðɛm, ən ɪz feɪs noʊ lɔŋɡɝ keɪm əz fɑɹ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ wɪð itʃ stʃɹoʊk. hi kɔft fɹəm wɔɾɝ ðət wɛn ʌp ɪz noʊz. ə deɪ ət ðə fɔɹdʒ əz noʊ ɑdz ɑn ðɪs, hi θɔt wɛɹəli, ən dʒʌs ðən ɪz kɪkɪŋ fʊt stʃɹʌk sʌmθɪŋ. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əntɪl i kɪkt ɪɾ əɡɛn ðəɾ i ɹilaɪzd wʌɾ ɪt wɑz. ðə bɑɾəm. hi wɑz ɪn ðə ʃæloʊz. hi wɑz əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ.

After a while he was not even certain he would be able to lift the axe if Trollocs were there. His arms and legs became leaden; it was an effort to move them, and his face no longer came as far out of the river with each stroke. He coughed from water that went up his nose. A day at the forge has no odds on this, he thought wearily, and just then his kicking foot struck something. It was not until he kicked it again that he realized what it was. The bottom. He was in the shallows. He was across the river.

sʌkɪŋ ɛɹ θɹu hɪz maʊθ, hi ɡɑt tə hɪz fit, splæʃɪŋ əbaʊɾ əz ɪz lɛɡz ɔlmoʊst ɡeɪv weɪ. hi fʌmbəld ɪz æks aʊɾ ʌv ɪts lup əz i flaʊndɝɾ əʃɔɹ, ʃɪvɝɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd. hi dɪd nɑt si ɛni tʃɹɑləks. hi dɪd nɑt si ɛɡwin, iðɝ. dʒʌst ə fju skæɾɝd tʃɹiz əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk, ən ə munlaɪt ɹɪbən ɑn ðə wɔɾɝ.

Sucking air through his mouth, he got to his feet, splashing about as his legs almost gave way. He fumbled his axe out of its loop as he floundered ashore, shivering in the wind. He did not see any Trollocs. He did not see Egwene, either. Just a few scattered trees along the riverbank, and a moonlight ribbon on the water.

wən i hæɾ ɪz bɹɛθ əɡɛn, hi kɔl ðɛɹ neɪmz əɡɛn ən əɡɛn. feɪnt ʃaʊts fɹəm ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ænsɝd hɪm; ivən ət ðət dɪstəns i kəd meɪk aʊt ðə hɑɹʃ vɔɪsəz ə tʃɹɑləks. hɪz fɹɛnz dɪd nɑɾ ænsɝ, ðoʊ.

When he had his breath again, he called their names again and again. Faint shouts from the far side answered him; even at that distance he could make out the harsh voices of Trollocs. His friends did not answer, though.

ðə wɪn sɝdʒd, ɪts moʊn dʒɹaʊnɪŋ aʊt ðə tʃɹɑləks, ən i ʃɪvɝd. ɪt wɑz nɑt koʊld ɪnʌf tə fɹiz ðə wɔɾɝ soʊkɪŋ ɪz kloʊðz, bʌɾ ɪt fɛlt əz ɪf ɪt wɑz; ɪt slaɪs tə ðə boʊn wɪð ən aɪsi bleɪd. hʌɡɪŋ hɪmsɛlf wɑz oʊnli ə dʒɛstʃɝ ðət dɪd nɑt stɑp ðə ʃɪvɝɪŋ. əloʊn, hi klaɪm taɪɹədli ʌp ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk tə faɪnd ʃɛltɝ əɡɛns ðə wɪnd.

The wind surged, its moan drowning out the Trollocs, and he shivered. It was not cold enough to freeze the water soaking his clothes, but it felt as if it was; it sliced to the bone with an icy blade. Hugging himself was only a gesture that did not stop the shivering. Alone, he climbed tiredly up the riverbank to find shelter against the wind.

ɹænd pæɾəd klaʊdz nɛk, suðɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪ wɪð wɪspɝz. ðə hɔɹs tɔst ɪz hɛɾ ən dænst ɑn kwɪk fit. ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd bɪn lɛf bɪhaɪnd - əɹ soʊ ɪt simd - bʌt klaʊd hæd ðə smɛl ə ðɛm θɪk ɪn ɪz nɑstʃɹəlz. mæt ɹoʊd wɪð ən æɹoʊ nɑkt, wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ sɝpɹaɪzəz aʊɾ ə ðə naɪt, waɪl ɹænd ən tɑm pɪɹd θɹu ðə bɹæntʃəz, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɹɛd stɑɹ ðət wɑz ðɛɹ ɡaɪd. kipɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn vju hæd bɪn izi ɪnʌf, ivən wɪð ɔl ðə bɹæntʃəz oʊvɝhɛd, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪɾɪŋ stʃɹeɪt təwɔɹɾ ɪt. bʌt ðən mɔɹ tʃɹɑləks hæɾ əpɪɹd, əhɛd, ən ðeɪ wɛnt ɡæləpɪŋ ɔf tə ðə saɪd wɪð boʊθ pæks haʊlɪŋ æftɝ ðɛm. ðə tʃɹɑləks kəd kip ʌp wɪð ə hɔɹs, bʌɾ oʊnli fəɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əɹ soʊ, ən faɪnəli ðeɪ lɛf ðə pɝsuɾ ən ðə haʊlz bɪhaɪnd. bʌt wɪð ɔl ðə twɪsts ən tɝnz, ðeɪ hæd lɔs ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ stɑɹ.

Rand patted Cloud's neck, soothing the gray with whispers. The horse tossed his head and danced on quick feet. The Trollocs had been left behind - or so it seemed - but Cloud had the smell of them thick in his nostrils. Mat rode with an arrow nocked, watching for surprises out of the night, while Rand and Thom peered through the branches, searching for the red star that was their guide. Keeping it in view had been easy enough, even with all the branches overhead, so long as they were riding straight toward it. But then more Trollocs had appeared, ahead, and they went galloping off to the side with both packs howling after them. The Trollocs could keep up with a horse, but only for a hundred paces or so, and finally they left the pursuit and the howls behind. But with all the twists and turns, they had lost the guiding star.

"aɪ stɪl seɪ ɪts oʊvɝ ðɛɹ," mæt sɛd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ ɔf tə hɪz ɹaɪt. "wi wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ nɔɹθ ət ði ɛnd, ən ðət minz ist ɪz ðət weɪ."

"I still say it's over there," Mat said, gesturing off to his right. "We were going north at the end, and that means east is that way."

"ðɛɹ ɪɾ ɪz," tɑm sɛɾ əbɹʌpli. hi pɔɪntəd θɹu ðə tæŋɡəl bɹæntʃəz tə ðɛɹ lɛft, stʃɹeɪɾ ət ðə ɹɛd stɑɹ. mæt mʌmbəl sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ.

"There it is," Thom said abruptly. He pointed through the tangled branches to their left, straight at the red star. Mat mumbled something under his breath.

aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ ɹænd kɑt ðə muvmən əz ə tʃɹɑlɑk lɛpt aʊt fɹəm bɪhaɪn ə tʃɹi wɪθaʊɾ ə saʊnd, swɪŋɪŋ ɪts kætʃpoʊl. ɹænd dʌɡ hɪz hilz ɪn, ən ðə ɡɹeɪ baʊndəd fɔɹwɝd dʒʌst əz tu mɔɹ plʌnʒd fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz æftɝ ðə fɝst. ə nus bɹʌʃt ðə bæk ə ɹændz nɛk, sɛndɪŋ ə ʃɪvɝ daʊn ɪz spaɪn.

Out of the corner of his eye Rand caught the movement as a Trolloc leaped out from behind a tree without a sound, swinging its catchpole. Rand dug his heels in, and the gray bounded forward just as two more plunged from the shadows after the first. A noose brushed the back of Rand's neck, sending a shiver down his spine.

ən æɹoʊ tʊk wʌn ə ðə bɛstʃəl feɪsəz ɪn ði aɪ, ðən mæt swʌŋ ɪn bɪsaɪɾ ɪm əz ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz paʊndɪd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz. ðeɪ wɝ ɹʌnɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɹɪvɝ, hi ɹilaɪzd, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz gɑnə də ɛni ɡʊd. ðə tʃɹɑləks spɛɾ æftɝ ðɛm, ɔlmoʊs kloʊs ɪnʌf tə ɹitʃ aʊɾ ən ɡɹæb ðə stʃɹimɪŋ teɪlz ə ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. hæf ə stɛp ɡeɪnd, ən ðə kætʃpoʊlz kəd dʒɹæɡ ðɛm boʊθ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ sæɾəlz.

An arrow took one of the bestial faces in the eye, then Mat swung in beside him as their horses pounded through the trees. They were running toward the river, he realized, but he was not sure it was going to do any good. The Trollocs sped after them, almost close enough to reach out and grab the streaming tails of their horses. Half a step gained, and the catchpoles could drag them both out of their saddles.

hi lin loʊ ɑn ðə ɡɹeɪz nɛk tə pʊt ðət mʌtʃ mɔɹ dɪstəns bɪtwin ɪz oʊn nɛk ən ðə nusəz. mæts feɪs wɑz nɪɹli bɛɹiɾ ɪn ɪz hɔɹsəz meɪn. bʌt ɹænd wʌndɝd wɛɹ tɑm wɑz. hæd ðə ɡlimən dɪsaɪɾɪd i wɑz bɛɾɝ ɔf ɑn ɪz oʊn, sɪns ɔl θɹi tʃɹɑləks hæd fæsən ɑn ðə bɔɪz?

He leaned low on the gray's neck to put that much more distance between his own neck and the nooses. Mat's face was nearly buried in his horse's mane. But Rand wondered where Thom was. Had the gleeman decided he was better off on his own, since all three Trollocs had fastened on the boys?

sʌɾənli tɑmz ɡɛldɪŋ ɡæləpt aʊɾ ə ðə naɪt, hɑɹd bɪhaɪn ðə tʃɹɑləks. ðə tʃɹɑləks hæɾ oʊnli taɪm ɪnʌf tə lʊk bæk ɪn sɝpɹaɪz bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡlimənz hænz wɪp bæk ən ðən fɔɹwɝd. munlaɪt flæʃt ɔf stil. wʌn tʃɹɑlɑk tʌmbəl fɔɹwɝd, ɹoʊlɪŋ oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ bɪfɔɹ lændɪŋ ɪn ə hip, waɪl ə sɛkən dʒɹɑp tə ɪts niz wɪð ə skɹim, klɔɪŋ əɾ ɪts bæk wɪð boʊθ hænz. ðə θɝd snɑɹəld, bɛɹɪŋ ə mʌzəlfəl ə ʃɑɹp tiθ, bʌɾ əz ɪts kəmpænjənz tɑpəld ɪt wɝld əweɪ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs. tɑmz hæn meɪd ðə wɪp-laɪk moʊʃən əɡɛn, ən ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ʃɹikt, bʌt ðə ʃɹiks feɪɾəd ɪndə ðə dɪstəns əz ɪt ɹæn.

Suddenly Thom's gelding galloped out of the night, hard behind the Trollocs. The Trollocs had only time enough to look back in surprise before the gleeman's hands whipped back and then forward. Moonlight flashed off steel. One Trolloc tumbled forward, rolling over and over before landing in a heap, while a second dropped to its knees with a scream, clawing at its back with both hands. The third snarled, baring a muzzleful of sharp teeth, but as its companions toppled it whirled away into the darkness. Thom's hand made the whip-like motion again, and the Trolloc shrieked, but the shrieks faded into the distance as it ran.

ɹænd ən mæt pʊld ʌp ən stɛɹɾ ət ðə ɡlimən.

Rand and Mat pulled up and stared at the gleeman.

"maɪ sɛkənd-bɛs naɪvz," tɑm mʌɾɝd, bʌɾ i meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə ɡɛt daʊn ən ɹɪtʃɹiv ðɛm. "ðæt wʌn wɪl bɹɪŋ ʌðɝz. aɪ hoʊp ðə ɹɪvɝ ɪzən tu fɑɹ. aɪ hoʊp. . . ." ɪnstɛɾ ə seɪɪŋ wʌɾ ɛls i hoʊpt, hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ən sɛɾ ɔf əɾ ə kwɪk kæntɝ. ɹænd ən mæt fɛl ɪn bɪhaɪn hɪm.

"My second-best knives," Thom muttered, but he made no effort to get down and retrieve them. "That one will bring others. I hope the river isn't too far. I hope. . . ." Instead of saying what else he hoped, he shook his head and set off at a quick canter. Rand and Mat fell in behind him.

sun ðeɪ ɹitʃt ə loʊ bæŋk wɛɹ tʃɹiz ɡɹu ɹaɪt tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə naɪt-blæk wɔɾɝ, ɪts mun-stʃɹik sɝfəs ɹɪfəl baɪ ðə wɪnd. ɹænd kəd nɑt si ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ əɾ ɔl. hi dɪd nɑt laɪk ði aɪdiə ʌv kɹɔsɪŋ ɑn ə ɹæft ɪn ðə dɑɹk, bʌɾ i laɪk ði aɪdiə ʌv steɪɪŋ ɑn ðɪs saɪɾ ivən lɛs. əl swɪm ɪf aɪ hæv tə.

Soon they reached a low bank where trees grew right to the edge of the night-black water, its moon-streaked surface riffled by the wind. Rand could not see the far side at all. He did not like the idea of crossing on a raft in the dark, but he liked the idea of staying on this side even less. I'll swim if I have to.

sʌmwɛɹ əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ ə tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹn bɹeɪd, ʃɑɹp, kwɪk, ən ɝdʒən ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. ɪt wɑz ðə fɝst saʊn fɹəm ðə hɔɹnz sɪns ðeɪ hæd lɛf ðə ɹuənz. ɹænd wʌndɝɾ ɪf ɪt mɛn səm ə ði ʌðɝz hæd bɪn kæptʃɝd.

Somewhere away from the river a Trolloc horn brayed, sharp, quick, and urgent in the darkness. It was the first sound from the horns since they had left the ruins. Rand wondered if it meant some of the others had been captured.

"noʊ jus steɪɪŋ hɪɹ ɔl naɪt," tɑm sɛd. "pɪk ə dɝɛkʃən. ʌpɹɪvɝ, əɹ daʊn?"

"No use staying here all night," Thom said. "Pick a direction. Upriver, or down?"

"bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn ən ði ʌðɝz kəd bi ɛniwɛɹ," mæt pɹətɛstəd. "ɛni weɪ wi tʃuz kəd dʒʌs teɪk əs fɝðɝ əweɪ."

"But Moiraine and the others could be anywhere," Mat protested. "Any way we choose could just take us further away."

"soʊ ɪt kʊd." klʌkɪŋ tə hɪz ɡɛldɪŋ, tɑm tɝn daʊnɹɪvɝ, hɛɾɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə bæŋk. "soʊ ɪt kʊd." ɹænd lʊkt ət mæt, hu ʃɹʌɡd, ən ðeɪ tɝn æftɝ hɪm.

"So it could." Clucking to his gelding, Thom turned downriver, heading along the bank. "So it could." Rand looked at Mat, who shrugged, and they turned after him.

fəɹ ə taɪm nʌθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd. ðə bæŋk wɑz haɪɝ ɪn səm pleɪsəz, loʊɝ ɪn ʌðɝz, ðə tʃɹiz ɡɹu θɪkɝ, əɹ θɪn aʊɾ ɪn smɔl klɪɹɪŋz, bʌt ðə naɪɾ ən ðə ɹɪvɝ ən ðə wɪnd wɝ ɔl ðə seɪm, koʊld ən blæk. ən noʊ tʃɹɑləks. ðət wɑz wʌn tʃeɪnʒ ɹænd wɑz ɡlæd tə fɔɹɡoʊ.

For a time nothing changed. The bank was higher in some places, lower in others, the trees grew thicker, or thinned out in small clearings, but the night and the river and the wind were all the same, cold and black. And no Trollocs. That was one change Rand was glad to forgo.

ðən i sɔ ə laɪɾ əhɛd, dʒʌst ə sɪŋɡəl pɔɪnt. əz ðeɪ dʒɹu kloʊsɝ i kəd si ðət ðə laɪt wɑz wɛl əbʌv ðə ɹɪvɝ, əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ɪn ə tʃɹi. tɑm kwɪkən ðə peɪs ən bɪɡæn tə hʌm ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ.

Then he saw a light ahead, just a single point. As they drew closer he could see that the light was well above the river, as if it were in a tree. Thom quickened the pace and began to hum under his breath.

faɪnəli ðeɪ kəd meɪk aʊt ðə sɔɹs ə ðə laɪt, ə læntɝn hɔɪstəɾ ətɑp wʌn ə ðə mæsts ʌv ə lɑɹdʒ tʃɹeɪɾɝz boʊt, taɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ðə naɪt bɪsaɪɾ ə smɔl klɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðə tʃɹiz. ðə boʊt, ə ɡʊɾ eɪɾi fit lɔŋ, ʃɪftəd slaɪtli wɪð ðə kɝənt, tʌɡɪŋ əɡɛns ðə mʊɹɪŋ ɹoʊps taɪd tə tʃɹiz. ðə ɹɪɡɪŋ hʌmd ən kɹikt ɪn ðə wɪnd. ðə læntɝn dʌbəl ðə munlaɪɾ ɑn ðə dɛk, bʌt noʊ wʌn wɑz ɪn saɪt.

Finally they could make out the source of the light, a lantern hoisted atop one of the masts of a large trader's boat, tied up for the night beside a small clearing in the trees. The boat, a good eighty feet long, shifted slightly with the current, tugging against the mooring ropes tied to trees. The rigging hummed and creaked in the wind. The lantern doubled the moonlight on the deck, but no one was in sight.

"naʊ ðæt," tɑm sɛɾ əz i dɪsmaʊntɪd, "ɪz bɛɾɝ ðən ən ɛɛs sədaɪz ɹæft, ɪzən ɪt?" hi stʊd wɪð ɪz hænz ɑn ɪz hɪps, ən ivən ɪn ðə dɑɹk ɪz smʌɡnəs wɑz əpɛɹənt. "ɪt dʌzn lʊk əz ɪf ðɪs vɛsəl ɪz meɪd tə kæɹi hɔɹsəz, bʌt kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðə deɪnʒɝ hiz ɪn, wɪtʃ wəɹ gɑnə wɔɹn ɪm ʌv, ðə kæptən meɪ bi ɹizənəbəl. dʒʌs lemi də ɔl ðə tɔkɪŋ. ən bɹɪŋ jəɹ blæŋkəts ən sæɾəlbæɡz, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs."

"Now that," Thom said as he dismounted, "is better than an Aes Sedai's raft, isn't it?" He stood with his hands on his hips, and even in the dark his smugness was apparent. "It doesn't look as if this vessel is made to carry horses, but considering the danger he's in, which we are going to warn him of, the captain may be reasonable. Just let me do all the talking. And bring your blankets and saddlebags, just in case."

ɹænd klaɪm daʊn ən bɪɡæn əntiɪŋ ðə θɪŋz bɪhaɪn ɪz sæɾəl. "ju doʊn min tə liv wɪθaʊt ði ʌðɝz, də ju?"

Rand climbed down and began untying the things behind his saddle. "You don't mean to leave without the others, do you?"

tɑm hæd noʊ tʃæns tə seɪ wʌɾ i mɛn tə du. ɪndə ðə klɪɹɪŋ bɝs tu tʃɹɑləks, haʊlɪŋ ən weɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ kætʃpoʊlz, wɪð fɔɹ mɔɹ ɹaɪt bɪhaɪnd. ðə hɔɹsəz ɹɪɹɾ ən wɪnid. ʃaʊts ɪn ðə dɪstəns sɛd mɔɹ tʃɹɑləks wɝ ɑn ðə weɪ.

Thom had no chance to say what he meant to do. Into the clearing burst two Trollocs, howling and waving their catchpoles, with four more right behind. The horses reared and whinnied. Shouts in the distance said more Trollocs were on the way.

"ɑntu ðə boʊt!" tɑm ʃaʊɾəd. "kwɪk! liv ɔl ðæt! ɹʌn!" suɾɪŋ ɪz oʊn wɝdz, hi ɹæn fəɹ ðə boʊt, pætʃəz flæpɪŋ ən ɪnstʃɹəmən keɪsəz ɑn ɪz bæk bæŋɪŋ təɡɛðɝ. "ju ɑn ðə boʊt!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. "weɪk ʌp, jə fulz! tʃɹɑləks!"

"Onto the boat!" Thom shouted. "Quick! Leave all that! Run!" Suiting his own words, he ran for the boat, patches flapping and instrument cases on his back banging together. "You on the boat!" he shouted. "Wake up, you fools! Trollocs!"

ɹænd dʒɝkt ɪz blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl ən sæɾəlbæɡz fɹi ʌv ðə læs θɔŋ ən wɑz ɹaɪɾ ɑn ðə ɡlimənz hilz. tɔsɪŋ ɪz bɝɾənz oʊvɝ ðə ɹeɪl, hi vɔltəɾ æftɝ ðɛm. hi dʒʌs hæd taɪm tə si ə mæn kɝld ʌp ɑn ðə dɛk, bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə sɪɾ ʌp əz ɪf i hæɾ oʊnli ðət moʊmən əweɪkənd, wən ɪz fit keɪm daʊn ɹaɪɾ ɑn tɑp ə ðə fɛloʊ. ðə mæn ɡɹʌntɪd laʊdli, ɹænd stʌmbəld, ən ə hʊkt kætʃpoʊl slæmd ɪndə ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ dʒʌst wɛɹ i hæd kʌm oʊvɝ. ʃaʊts ɹoʊz ɔl oʊvɝ ðə boʊt, ən fit paʊndɪɾ əlɔŋ ðə dɛk.

Rand jerked his blanketroll and saddlebags free of the last thong and was right on the gleeman's heels. Tossing his burdens over the rail, he vaulted after them. He just had time to see a man curled up on the deck, beginning to sit up as if he had only that moment awakened, when his feet came down right on top of the fellow. The man grunted loudly, Rand stumbled, and a hooked catchpole slammed into the railing just where he had come over. Shouts rose all over the boat, and feet pounded along the deck.

hɛɹi hænz kɑt ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə kætʃpoʊl, ən ə ɡoʊt-hɔɹn hɛd lɪftəɾ əbʌv ɪt. ɔf bæləns, stʌmbəlɪŋ, ɹænd stɪl mænədʒ tə dʒɹɔ hɪz sɔɹɾ ən swɪŋ. wɪð ə skɹim ðə tʃɹɑlɑk dʒɹɑpt əweɪ.

Hairy hands caught the railing beside the catchpole, and a goat-horned head lifted above it. Off balance, stumbling, Rand still managed to draw his sword and swing. With a scream the Trolloc dropped away.

mɛn ɹæn ɛvɹiwɛɹ ɑn ðə boʊt, ʃaʊɾɪŋ, hækɪŋ mʊɹɪŋ laɪnz wɪð æksɪz. ðə boʊt lɝtʃt ən swʌŋ əz ɪf iɡɝ tə bi ɔf. ʌp ɪn ðə baʊ θɹi mɛn stʃɹʌɡəld wɪð ə tʃɹɑlɑk. sʌmwʌn θɹʌst oʊvɝ ðə saɪd wɪð ə spɪɹ, ðoʊ ɹænd kəd nɑt si wʌɾ i wɑz stæbɪŋ æt. ə bɑstʃɹɪŋ snæpt, ən snæpt əɡɛn. ðə mæn ɹænd hæd stɛpt ɑn skɹæbəld əweɪ fɹəm ɪm ɑn hænz ən niz, ðən flʌŋ ʌp ɪz hænz wən i sɔ ɹænd lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm.

Men ran everywhere on the boat, shouting, hacking mooring lines with axes. The boat lurched and swung as if eager to be off. Up in the bow three men struggled with a Trolloc. Someone thrust over the side with a spear, though Rand could not see what he was stabbing at. A bowstring snapped, and snapped again. The man Rand had stepped on scrabbled away from him on hands and knees, then flung up his hands when he saw Rand looking at him.

"spɛɹ mi!" hi kɹaɪd. "teɪk wʌtɛvɝ jə wɑnt, teɪk ðə boʊt, teɪk ɛvɹiθɪŋ, bʌt spɛɹ mi!"

"Spare me!" he cried. "Take whatever you want, take the boat, take everything, but spare me!"

sʌɾənli sʌmθɪŋ slæmd əkɹɔs ɹændz bæk, smæʃɪŋ ɪm tə ðə dɛk. hɪz sɔɹd skɪɾɝd əweɪ fɹəm ɪz aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt hænd. oʊpənməðd, ɡæspɪŋ fəɹ ə bɹɛθ ðət wəd nɑt kʌm, hi tʃɹaɪd tə ɹitʃ ðə sɔɹd. hɪz mʌsəlz ɹɪspɑndɪd wɪð æɡənaɪz sloʊnəs; hi ɹɪθ laɪk ə slʌɡ. ðə fɛloʊ hu wɑntəd tə bi spɛɹd ɡeɪv wʌn fɹaɪɾənd, kʌvtəs lʊk ət ðə sɔɹd, ðən vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊz.

Suddenly something slammed across Rand's back, smashing him to the deck. His sword skittered away from his outstretched hand. Openmouthed, gasping for a breath that would not come, he tried to reach the sword. His muscles responded with agonized slowness; he writhed like a slug. The fellow who wanted to be spared gave one frightened, covetous look at the sword, then vanished into the shadows.

peɪnfəli ɹænd mænədʒ tə lʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ən nu hɪz lʌk hæd ɹʌn aʊt. ə wʊlf-mʌzəl tʃɹɑlɑk stʊd bælənst ɑn ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ, stɛɹɪŋ daʊn əɾ ɪm ən hoʊldɪŋ ðə splɪntɝɾ ɛn ə ðə kætʃpoʊl ðət hæd nɑk ðə wɪn aʊɾ ə hɪm. ɹænd stʃɹʌɡəl tə ɹitʃ ðə sɔɹd, tə muv, tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ, bʌɾ ɪz ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz muv dʒɝkəli, ən oʊnli hæf əz i wɑntəd. ðeɪ wɑbəld ən wɛn ɪn ɑd dɝɛkʃənz. hɪz tʃɛs fɛlt əz ɪf ɪt wɝ stʃɹæpt wɪð aɪɝn bænz; sɪlvɝ spɑts swæm ɪn ɪz aɪz. fɹæntəkəli hi hʌntəd fəɹ səm weɪ tə ɪskeɪp. taɪm sim tə sloʊ əz ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ɹeɪz ðə dʒæɡd poʊl əz ɪf tə spɪɹ ɪm wɪð ɪt. tə ɹænd ðə kɹitʃɝ əpɪɹd tə bi muvɪŋ əz ɪf ɪn ə dʒɹim. hi wɑtʃt ðə θɪk ɑɹm ɡoʊ bæk; hi kəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi fil ðə bɹoʊkən hæft ɹɪpɪŋ θɹu hɪz spaɪn, fil ðə peɪn ʌv ɪt tɛɹɪŋ ɪm oʊpən. hi θɔɾ ɪz lʌŋz wəd bɝst. aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ! laɪt hɛlp mi, aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə . . . ! ðə tʃɹɑlɑks ɑɹm stɑɹɾəd fɔɹwɝd, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ðə splɪntɝd ʃæft, ən ɹænd faʊn ðə bɹɛθ fəɹ wʌn jɛl. "noʊ!"

Painfully Rand managed to look over his shoulder, and knew his luck had run out. A wolf-muzzled Trolloc stood balanced on the railing, staring down at him and holding the splintered end of the catchpole that had knocked the wind out of him. Rand struggled to reach the sword, to move, to get away, but his arms and legs moved jerkily, and only half as he wanted. They wobbled and went in odd directions. His chest felt as if it were strapped with iron bands; silver spots swam in his eyes. Frantically he hunted for some way to escape. Time seemed to slow as the Trolloc raised the jagged pole as if to spear him with it. To Rand the creature appeared to be moving as if in a dream. He watched the thick arm go back; he could already feel the broken haft ripping through his spine, feel the pain of it tearing him open. He thought his lungs would burst. I'm going to die! Light help me, I'm going to . . . ! The Trolloc's arm started forward, driving the splintered shaft, and Rand found the breath for one yell. "No!"

sʌɾənli ðə ʃɪp lɝtʃt, ən ə bum swʌŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊz tə kætʃ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk əkɹɔs ðə tʃɛst wɪð ə kɹʌntʃ ə bɹeɪkɪŋ boʊnz, swipɪŋ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə saɪd.

Suddenly the ship lurched, and a boom swung out of the shadows to catch the Trolloc across the chest with a crunch of breaking bones, sweeping it over the side.

fəɹ ə moʊmən ɹænd leɪ pæntɪŋ ən stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət ðə bum swɪŋɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ əbʌv hɪm. ðəɾ əz tə hæv juzd ʌp maɪ lʌk, hi θɔt. ðəɹ kæn bi ɛni mɔɹ æftɝ ðæt.

For a moment Rand lay panting and staring up at the boom swinging back and forth above him. That has to have used up my luck, he thought. There can't be any more after that.

ʃɑkəli hi ɡɑt tə hɪz fiɾ ən pɪkt ʌp ɪz sɔɹd, fəɹ wʌns hoʊldɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn boʊθ hænz ðə weɪ læn hæd tɔt hɪm, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ lɛft ɑn wɪtʃ tə juz ɪt. ðə ɡæp ə blæk wɔɾɝ bɪtwin ðə boʊɾ ən ðə bæŋk wɑz waɪɾənɪŋ kwɪkli; ðə kɹaɪz ə ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ feɪɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪn ðə naɪt.

Shakily he got to his feet and picked up his sword, for once holding it in both hands the way Lan had taught him, but there was nothing left on which to use it. The gap of black water between the boat and the bank was widening quickly; the cries of the Trollocs were fading behind in the night.

əz i ʃiðd ɪz sɔɹɾ ən slʌmpt əɡɛns ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ, ə stɑki mæn ɪn ə koʊt ðət hʌŋ tə hɪz niz stʃɹoʊɾ ʌp ðə dɛk tə ɡlɛɹ ət hɪm. lɔŋ hɛɹ ðət fɛl tə hɪz θɪk ʃoʊldɝz ən ə bɪɹd ðət lɛft ɪz ʌpɝ lɪp bɛɹ fɹeɪmd ə ɹaʊn feɪs. ɹaʊn bʌt nɑt sɑft. ðə bum swʌŋ aʊɾ əɡɛn, ən ðə bɪɹɾəd mæn spɛɹd pɑɹɾ ə hɪz ɡlɛɹ fəɹ ðəɾ əz i kɑɾ ɪt; ɪt meɪɾ ə kɹɪsp splæɾ əɡɛnst ɪz bɹɔd pɑm.

As he sheathed his sword and slumped against the railing, a stocky man in a coat that hung to his knees strode up the deck to glare at him. Long hair that fell to his thick shoulders and a beard that left his upper lip bare framed a round face. Round but not soft. The boom swung out again, and the bearded man spared part of his glare for that as he caught it; it made a crisp splat against his broad palm.

"dʒɛlb!" hi bɛloʊd. "fɔɹtʃən! wɛɹ dʒju bi, dʒɛlb?" hi spoʊk soʊ fæst, wɪð ɔl ðə wɝdz ɹʌnɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, ðət ɹænd kəd bɛɹli ʌndɝstæn hɪm. "ju kən noʊ haɪd fɹəm mi ɑn maɪ oʊn ʃɪp! ɡɛt flɔɹən dʒɛlb aʊt hɪɹ!"

"Gelb!" he bellowed. "Fortune! Where do you be, Gelb?" He spoke so fast, with all the words running together, that Rand could barely understand him. "You can no hide from me on my own ship! Get Floran Gelb out here!"

ə kɹumən əpɪɹd wɪð ə bʊlz-aɪ læntɝn, ən tu mɔɹ pʊʃt ə nɛɹoʊ-feɪs mæn ɪndə ðə sɝkəl ə laɪɾ ɪt kæst. ɹænd ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə fɛloʊ hu hæɾ ɔfɝɾ ɪm ðə boʊt. ðə mænz aɪz ʃɪftəd fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd, nɛvɝ miɾɪŋ ðoʊz ə ðə stɑki mæn. ðə kæptən, ɹænd θɔt. ə bɹuz wɑz kʌmɪŋ ʌp ɑn dʒɛlbz fɔɹhɛd wɛɹ wʌn ə ɹændz buts hæd kɑt hɪm.

A crewman appeared with a bull's-eye lantern, and two more pushed a narrow-faced man into the circle of light it cast. Rand recognized the fellow who had offered him the boat. The man's eyes shifted from side to side, never meeting those of the stocky man. The captain, Rand thought. A bruise was coming up on Gelb's forehead where one of Rand's boots had caught him.

"wɝ jə noʊ səpoʊz tə sɪkjʊɹ ðɪs bum, dʒɛlb?" ðə kæptən æskt wɪð sɝpɹaɪzɪŋ kɑm, ðoʊ dʒʌst əz fæst əz bɪfɔɹ.

"Were you no supposed to secure this boom, Gelb?" the captain asked with surprising calm, though just as fast as before.

dʒɛlb lʊk tʃɹuli sɝpɹaɪzd. "bʌɾ aɪ dɪd. taɪɾ ɪt daʊn taɪt. aɪ ədmɪɾ ɪm ə lɪɾəl sloʊ əbaʊt θɪŋz naʊ ən ðɛn, kæptən doʊmən, bʌɾ aɪ ɡɛɾ əm dʌn."

Gelb looked truly surprised. "But I did. Tied it down tight. I admit I'm a little slow about things now and then, Captain Domon, but I get them done."

"soʊ jə bi sloʊ, də ju? noʊ soʊ sloʊ ət slipɪŋ. slipɪŋ wən jə ʃəd bi stændɪŋ wɑtʃ. wi kəd bi mɝɾɝd tə ə mæn, fəɹ ɔl ə ju."

"So you be slow, do you? No so slow at sleeping. Sleeping when you should be standing watch. We could be murdered to a man, for all of you."

"noʊ, kæptən, noʊ. ɪt wɑz hɪm." dʒɛlb pɔɪntəd stʃɹeɪɾ ət ɹænd. "aɪ wɑz ɑn ɡɑɹd, dʒʌs laɪk aɪ wɑz səpoʊz tə bi, wən i snikt ʌp ən hɪt mi wɪð ə klʌb." hi tʌtʃt ðə bɹuz ɑn ɪz hɛd, wɪnst, ən ɡlɛɹɾ ət ɹænd. "aɪ fɔt hɪm, bʌt ðən ðə tʃɹɑləks keɪm. hiz ɪn liɡ wɪð ðɛm, kæptən. eɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnd. ɪn liɡ wɪð ðə tʃɹɑləks."

"No, Captain, no. It was him." Gelb pointed straight at Rand. "I was on guard, just like I was supposed to be, when he sneaked up and hit me with a club." He touched the bruise on his head, winced, and glared at Rand. "I fought him, but then the Trollocs came. He's in league with them, Captain. A Darkfriend. In league with the Trollocs."

"ɪn liɡ wɪð maɪ eɪdʒd ɡɹændmʌðɝ!" kæptən doʊmən ɹɔɹd. "dɪɾ aɪ noʊ wɔɹn jə ðə læs taɪm, dʒɛlb? ət waɪtbɹɪdʒ, ɔf jə də ɡoʊ! ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə maɪ saɪt bɪfɔɹ aɪ pʊt jə ɔf naʊ." dʒɛlb dɑɹɾɪd aʊɾ ə ðə læntɝn laɪt, ən doʊmən stʊɾ oʊpənɪŋ ən kloʊzɪŋ ɪz hænz waɪl i stɛɹɾ ət nʌθɪŋ. "ðiz tʃɹɑləks də bi fɑloʊɪŋ mi. waɪ wɪl ðeɪ noʊ liv mi bi? waɪ?"

"In league with my aged grandmother!" Captain Domon roared. "Did I no warn you the last time, Gelb? At Whitebridge, off you do go! Get out of my sight before I put you off now." Gelb darted out of the lantern light, and Domon stood opening and closing his hands while he stared at nothing. "These Trollocs do be following me. Why will they no leave me be? Why?"

ɹænd lʊkt oʊvɝ ðə ɹeɪl ən wɑz ʃɑk tə faɪn ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪn saɪt. tu mɛn mæn ðə lɔŋ stɪɹɪŋ ɔɹ ðət stʌk aʊɾ oʊvɝ ðə stɝn, ən ðəɹ wɝ sɪks swips wɝkɪŋ tə ə saɪd naʊ, pʊlɪŋ ðə ʃɪp laɪk ə wɔɾɝbʌɡ fɝðɝ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ.

Rand looked over the rail and was shocked to find the riverbank no longer in sight. Two men manned the long steering oar that stuck out over the stern, and there were six sweeps working to a side now, pulling the ship like a waterbug further out into the river.

"kæptən," ɹænd sɛd, "wi hæv fɹɛnz bæk ðɛɹ. ɪf jə ɡoʊ bæk ən pɪk əm ʌp, aɪm ʃʊɹ ðəl ɹɪwɔɹd ju."

"Captain," Rand said, "we have friends back there. If you go back and pick them up, I am sure they'll reward you."

ðə kæptənz ɹaʊn feɪs swʌŋ təwɔɹd ɹænd, ən wən tɑm ən mæt əpɪɹɾ i ɪnkluɾəd əm ɪn ɪz ɪkspɹɛʃənləs stɛɹ əz wɛl.

The captain's round face swung toward Rand, and when Thom and Mat appeared he included them in his expressionless stare as well.

"kæptən," tɑm bɪɡæn wɪð ə baʊ, "əlaʊ mi tə - "

"Captain," Thom began with a bow, "allow me to - "

"ju kʌm bɪloʊ," kæptən doʊmən sɛd, "wɛɹ aɪ kən si wʌt mænɝ ə θɪŋ bi hɔld ʌp ɑn maɪ dɛk. kʌm. fɔɹtʃən dɛzɝt mi, sʌmbɑɾi sɪkjʊɹ ðɪs hɔɹn-kɝs bum!" əz kɹumɪn ɹʌʃt tə teɪk ðə bum, hi stʌmpt ɔf təwɔɹd ðə stɝn ə ðə boʊt. ɹænd ən ɪz tu kəmpænjənz fɑloʊd.

"You come below," Captain Domon said, "where I can see what manner of thing be hauled up on my deck. Come. Fortune desert me, somebody secure this horn-cursed boom!" As crewmen rushed to take the boom, he stumped off toward the stern of the boat. Rand and his two companions followed.

kæptən doʊmən hæɾ ə taɪɾi kæbən ɪn ðə stɝn, ɹitʃt baɪ klaɪmɪŋ daʊn ə ʃɔɹt læɾɝ, wɛɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɡeɪv ði ɪmpɹɛʃən ə biɪŋ ɪn ɪts pɹɑpɝ pleɪs, ɹaɪt daʊn tə ðə koʊts ən kloʊks hæŋɪŋ fɹəm pɛɡz ɑn ðə bæk ə ðə dɔɹ. ðə kæbən stʃɹɛtʃt ðə wɪdθ ə ðə ʃɪp, wɪð ə bɹɔd bɛd bɪlt əɡɛnst wʌn saɪɾ ən ə hɛvi teɪbəl bɪlt aʊt fɹəm ði ʌðɝ. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn tʃɛɹ, wɪð ə haɪ bæk ən stɝɾi ɑɹmz, ən ðə kæptən tʊk ðət hɪmsɛlf, moʊʃənɪŋ ði ʌðɝz tə faɪn pleɪsəz ɑn vɛɹiəs tʃɛsts ən bɛntʃɪz ðət wɝ ði oʊnli ʌðɝ fɝnɪʃɪŋz. ə laʊd hæɹəmf stɑp mæt fɹəm sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə bɛd.

Captain Domon had a tidy cabin in the stern, reached by climbing down a short ladder, where everything gave the impression of being in its proper place, right down to the coats and cloaks hanging from pegs on the back of the door. The cabin stretched the width of the ship, with a broad bed built against one side and a heavy table built out from the other. There was only one chair, with a high back and sturdy arms, and the captain took that himself, motioning the others to find places on various chests and benches that were the only other furnishings. A loud harrumph stopped Mat from sitting on the bed.

"naʊ," sɛd ðə kæptən wən ðeɪ wɝ ɔl siɾəd. "maɪ neɪm bi beɪl doʊmən, kæptən ən oʊnɝ ə ðə spɹeɪ, wɪtʃ bi ðɪs ʃɪp. naʊ hu bi ju, ən wɛɹ bi jə ɡoʊɪŋ aʊt hɪɹ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə noʊwɛɹ, ən waɪ ʃəɾ aɪ noʊ θɹoʊ jə oʊvɝ ðə saɪd fəɹ ðə tʃɹʌbəl juv bɹɔt mi?"

"Now," said the captain when they were all seated. "My name be Bayle Domon, captain and owner of the Spray, which be this ship. Now who be you, and where be you going out here in the middle of nowhere, and why should I no throw you over the side for the trouble you've brought me?"

ɹænd stɪl hæɾ əz mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl əz bɪfɔɹ ɪn fɑloʊɪŋ doʊmənz ɹæpəd spitʃ. wən i wɝkt aʊt ðə læs pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt ðə kæptən hæd sɛɾ i blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. θɹoʊ əs oʊvɝ ðə saɪd?

Rand still had as much trouble as before in following Domon's rapid speech. When he worked out the last part of what the captain had said he blinked in surprise. Throw us over the side?

mæt hɝidli sɛd, "wi dɪdn min tə kɑz jə ɛni tʃɹʌbəl. wɝ ɑn əɹ weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn, ən ðən tə - "

Mat hurriedly said, "We didn't mean to cause you any trouble. We're on our way to Caemlyn, and then to - "

"æn ðən wɛɹ ðə wɪn teɪks ʌs," tɑm ɪntɝʌptɪd smuðli. "ðæts haʊ ɡlimən tʃɹævəl, laɪk dʌst ɑn ðə wɪnd. aɪm ə ɡlimən, jə ʌndɝstænd, tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn baɪ neɪm." hi ʃɪftəɾ ɪz kloʊk soʊ ðə mʌltəhud pætʃəz stɝd, əz ɪf ðə kæptən cʊɾə mɪs ðɛm. "ðiz tu kʌntʃɹi laʊts wɑnə bɪkʌm maɪ əpɹɛntəsɪz, ðoʊ aɪm nɑt jɛt ʃʊɹ aɪ wɑn ðɛm." ɹænd lʊkt ət mæt, hu ɡɹɪnd.

"And then where the wind takes us," Thom interrupted smoothly. "That's how gleemen travel, like dust on the wind. I am a gleeman, you understand, Thom Merrilin by name." He shifted his cloak so the multihued patches stirred, as if the captain could have missed them. "These two country louts want to become my apprentices, though I am not yet sure I want them." Rand looked at Mat, who grinned.

"ðæt bi ɔl vɛɹi wɛl, mæn," kæptən doʊmən sɛd plɑtʃədli, "bʌɾ ɪt tɛlz mi nʌθɪŋ. lɛs. fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi, ðət pleɪs bi ɑn noʊ ɹoʊd tə keɪɛmlɪn fɹəm ɛniwɛɹ aɪ ɛvɝ hɝd tɛl ʌv."

"That be all very well, man," Captain Domon said placidly, "but it tells me nothing. Less. Fortune prick me, that place be on no road to Caemlyn from anywhere I ever heard tell of."

"naʊ ðəɾ ɪz ə stɔɹi," tɑm sɛd, ən i stʃɹeɪɾəweɪ bɪɡæn tə ənfoʊld ɪt.

"Now that is a story," Thom said, and he straightaway began to unfold it.

əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə tɑm, hi hæd bɪn tʃɹæp baɪ ðə wɪntɝ snoʊz ɪn ə maɪnɪŋ taʊn ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪs bɪɑn bɛɹlən. waɪl ðəɹ i hɝd lɛdʒənz ʌv ə tʃɹɛʒɝ deɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, ɪn ðə lɔst ɹuən ʌv ə sɪɾi kɔld ɑɹɪdhɔl. naʊ ɪt dʒʌst soʊ hæpən ðəɾ i hæɾ ɝliɝ lɝn ðə loʊkeɪʃən ʌv ɑɹɪdhɔl fɹəm ə mæp ɡɪvən ɪm mɛni jɪɹz əɡoʊ baɪ ə daɪɪŋ fɹɛn ɪn ɪljən huz laɪf i hæd wʌns seɪvd, ə mæn u ɪkspaɪɹd bɹiðɪŋ ðət ðə mæp wəd meɪk tɑm ɹɪtʃ, wɪtʃ tɑm nɛvɝ bɪlivd əntɪl i hɝd ðə lɛdʒənz. wən ðə snoʊz mɛltəɾ ɪnʌf, hi sɛɾ aʊt wɪð ə fju kəmpænjənz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɪz tu wʊd-bi əpɹɛntəsɪz, ən æftɝ ə dʒɝni ʌv mɛni hɑɹdʃɪps ðeɪ æktʃəli  faʊn ðə ɹuən sɪɾi. bʌɾ ɪt tɝn aʊt ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ hæd bɪlɔŋ tə wʌn ə ðə dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz ðɛmsɛlvz, ən tʃɹɑləks hæd bɪn sɛn tə fɛtʃ ɪt bæk tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹi deɪnʒɝ ðeɪ ɹɪli hæd feɪst - tʃɹɑləks, mɹdʒɹɑl, dʒɹæɡkɝ, mɔɹɾɪθ, mɑʃəɾɝ - əseɪld əm ət wʌn pɔɪn əɹ ənʌðɝ ə ðə stɔɹi, ðoʊ ðə weɪ tɑm toʊld ɪt ðeɪ ɔl sim tə bi eɪmd əɾ ɪm pɝsənəli, ən tə hæv bɪn hændəl baɪ hɪm wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst ædʒɹɔɪɑtnəs. wɪð mʌtʃ dɛɹɪŋ-du, moʊsli baɪ tɑm, ðeɪ ɪskeɪpt, pɝsud baɪ tʃɹɑləks, ðoʊ ðeɪ bɪkeɪm sɛpɝeɪɾəd ɪn ðə naɪt, əntɪl faɪnəli tɑm ən ɪz tu kəmpænjənz sɔt ɹɛfjudʒ ɑn ðə læs pleɪs lɛf tə ðɛm, kæptən doʊmənz moʊst wɛlkəm ʃɪp.

According to Thom, he had been trapped by the winter snows in a mining town in the Mountains of Mist beyond Baerlon. While there he heard legends of a treasure dating from the Trolloc Wars, in the lost ruin of a city called Aridhol. Now it just so happened that he had earlier learned the location of Aridhol from a map given him many years ago by a dying friend in Illian whose life he had once saved, a man who expired breathing that the map would make Thom rich, which Thom never believed until he heard the legends. When the snows melted enough, he set out with a few companions, including his two would-be apprentices, and after a journey of many hardships they actually found the ruined city. But it turned out the treasure had belonged to one of the Dreadlords themselves, and Trollocs had been sent to fetch it back to Shayol Ghul. Almost every danger they really had faced - Trollocs, Myrddraal, Draghkar, Mordeth, Mashadar - assailed them at one point or another of the story, though the way Thom told it they all seemed to be aimed at him personally, and to have been handled by him with the greatest adroitness. With much derring-do, mostly by Thom, they escaped, pursued by Trollocs, though they became separated in the night, until finally Thom and his two companions sought refuge on the last place left to them, Captain Domon's most welcome ship.

əz ðə ɡlimən fɪnɪʃt ʌp, ɹænd ɹilaɪzd ɪz maʊθ hæd bɪn hæŋɪŋ oʊpən fəɹ səm taɪm ən ʃʌɾ ɪt wɪð ə klɪk. wən i lʊkt ət mæt, hɪz fɹɛnd wɑz stɛɹɪŋ waɪd-aɪɾ ət ðə ɡlimən.

As the gleeman finished up, Rand realized his mouth had been hanging open for some time and shut it with a click. When he looked at Mat, his friend was staring wide-eyed at the gleeman.

kæptən doʊmən dʒɹʌmd ɪz fɪŋɡɝz ɑn ði ɑɹm ə hɪz tʃɛɹ. "ðæt bi ə teɪl mɛni foʊk wəd noʊ bɪliv. ʌv kɔɹs, aɪ dɪd si ðə tʃɹɑləks, dɪɾ aɪ noʊ."

Captain Domon drummed his fingers on the arm of his chair. "That be a tale many folk would no believe. Of course, I did see the Trollocs, did I no."

"ɛvɹi wɝd tʃɹu," tɑm sɛd blænli, "fɹʌm wʌn u lɪvd ɪt."

"Every word true," Thom said blandly, "from one who lived it."

"hæpən juv səm ə ðɪs tʃɹɛʒɝ wɪð ju?"

"Happen you have some of this treasure with you?"

tɑm spɹɛɾ ɪz hænz ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli. "əlæs, wʌt lɪɾəl wi mænədʒ tə kæɹi əweɪ wɑz wɪð əɹ hɔɹsəz, wɪtʃ boʊltəd wən ðoʊz læs tʃɹɑləks əpɪɹd. ɔl aɪ hæv lɛft ɑɹ maɪ fluɾ ən maɪ hɑɹp, ə fju kɑpɝz, ən ðə kloʊðz ɑn maɪ bæk. bʌt bɪliv mi, jə wɑnt noʊ pɑɹɾ ə ðət tʃɹɛʒɝ. ɪts ðə teɪn ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. bɛs tə liv ɪt tə ðə ɹuənz ən ðə tʃɹɑləks."

Thom spread his hands regretfully. "Alas, what little we managed to carry away was with our horses, which bolted when those last Trollocs appeared. All I have left are my flute and my harp, a few coppers, and the clothes on my back. But believe me, you want no part of that treasure. It has the taint of the Dark One. Best to leave it to the ruins and the Trollocs."

"soʊ juv noʊ mʌni tə peɪ jəɹ pæsədʒ. aɪd noʊ lɛt maɪ oʊn bɹʌðɝ seɪl wɪð mi ɪf i kəd noʊ peɪ hɪz pæsədʒ, ɪspɛʃli ɪf i bɹɔt tʃɹɑləks bɪhaɪn ɪm tə hæk ʌp maɪ ɹeɪlɪŋz ən kʌɾ ʌp maɪ ɹɪɡɪŋ. waɪ ʃəɾ aɪ noʊ lɛt jə swɪm bæk wɛɹ jə keɪm fɹʌm, ən bi ɹɪɾ ə ju?"

"So you've no money to pay your passage. I'd no let my own brother sail with me if he could no pay his passage, especially if he brought Trollocs behind him to hack up my railings and cut up my rigging. Why should I no let you swim back where you came from, and be rid of you?"

"ju wʊdn dʒʌs pʊɾ əs əʃɔɹ?" mæt sɛd. "nɑt wɪð tʃɹɑləks ðɛɹ?"

"You wouldn't just put us ashore?" Mat said. "Not with Trollocs there?"

"hu sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt ʃɔɹ?" doʊmən ɹɪplaɪd dʒɹaɪli. hi stʌɾid əm ə moʊmənt, ðən spɹɛɾ ɪz hænz flæɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "beɪl doʊmən bi ə ɹizənəbəl mæn. aɪd noʊ tɔs jə oʊvɝ ðə saɪɾ ɪf ðəɹ bi ə weɪ aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. naʊ, aɪ si wʌn ə jəɹ əpɹɛntəsɪz əz ə sɔɹd. aɪ niɾ ə ɡʊd sɔɹd, ən faɪn fɛloʊ ðəɾ aɪ bi, əl lɛt juv pæsədʒ fɑɹ əz waɪtbɹɪdʒ fəɹ ɪt."

"Who said anything about shore?" Domon replied dryly. He studied them a moment, then spread his hands flat on the table. "Bayle Domon be a reasonable man. I'd no toss you over the side if there be a way out of it. Now, I see one of your apprentices has a sword. I need a good sword, and fine fellow that I be, I'll let you have passage far as Whitebridge for it."

tɑm oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ən ɹænd spoʊk ʌp kwɪkli, "noʊ!" tæm hæd nɑt ɡɪvən ɪt tə hɪm tə tʃɹeɪɾ əweɪ. hi ɹæn ɪz hæn daʊn ðə hɪlt, filɪŋ ðə bɹɑnz hɛɹən. əz lɔŋ əz i hæɾ ɪt, ɪt wɑz əz ɪf tæm wɝ wɪð hɪm.

Thom opened his mouth, and Rand spoke up quickly, "No!" Tam had not given it to him to trade away. He ran his hand down the hilt, feeling the bronze heron. As long as he had it, it was as if Tam were with him.

doʊmən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "wɛl, ɪf ɪt bi noʊ, ɪt bi noʊ. bʌt beɪl doʊmən noʊ ɡɪv fɹi pæsədʒ, nɑt tə hɪz oʊn mʌðɝ."

Domon shook his head. "Well, if it be no, it be no. But Bayle Domon no give free passage, not to his own mother."

ɹɪlʌktənli ɹænd ɛmptiɾ ɪz pɑkət. ðəɹ wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ, ə fju kɑpɝz ən ðə sɪlvɝ kɔɪn mɔɪɹeɪn hæd ɡɪvən hɪm. hi hɛld ɪɾ aʊt tə ðə kæptən. æftɝ ə sɛkənd, mæt saɪɾ ən dɪd ðə seɪm. tɑm ɡlɛɹd, bʌɾ ə smaɪl ɹipleɪst ɪt soʊ kwɪkli ðət ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪt hæd bɪn ðəɹ əɾ ɔl.

Reluctantly Rand emptied his pocket. There was not much, a few coppers and the silver coin Moiraine had given him. He held it out to the captain. After a second, Mat sighed and did the same. Thom glared, but a smile replaced it so quickly that Rand was not sure it had been there at all.

kæptən doʊmən dɛfli plʌk ðə tu fæt sɪlvɝ kɔɪnz aʊɾ ə ðə bɔɪz' hænz ən pɹədust ə smɔl sɛɾ ə skeɪlz ən ə klɪŋkɪŋ bæɡ fɹəm ə bɹæs-baʊn tʃɛs bɪhaɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ. æftɝ kɛɹfəl weɪɪŋ, hi dʒɹɑp ðə kɔɪnz ɪn ðə bæɡ ən ɹɪtɝn əm itʃ səm smɔlɝ sɪlvɝ ən kɑpɝ. moʊsli kɑpɝ. "æz fɑɹ əz waɪtbɹɪdʒ," hi sɛd, meɪkɪŋ ə niɾ ɛntʃɹi ɪn ə lɛðɝbaʊn lɛdʒɝ.

Captain Domon deftly plucked the two fat silver coins out of the boys' hands and produced a small set of scales and a clinking bag from a brass-bound chest behind his chair. After careful weighing, he dropped the coins in the bag and returned them each some smaller silver and copper. Mostly copper. "As far as Whitebridge," he said, making a neat entry in a leatherbound ledger.

"ðæts ə dɪɹ pæsədʒ dʒʌs tə waɪtbɹɪdʒ," tɑm ɡɹʌmbəld.

"That's a dear passage just to Whitebridge," Thom grumbled.

"plʌs dæmədʒəz tə maɪ vɛsəl," ðə kæptən ænsɝd plɑtʃədli. hi pʊt ðə skeɪlz ən ðə bæɡ bæk ɪn ðə tʃɛst ən kloʊzd ɪɾ ɪn ə sæɾəsfaɪd weɪ. "plʌs ə bɪt fəɹ bɹɪŋɪŋ tʃɹɑləks daʊn ɑn mi soʊ aɪ mʌst ɹʌn daʊnɹɪvɝ ɪn ðə naɪt wən ðəɹ bi ʃæloʊz əplɛnti tə paɪl mi ʌp."

"Plus damages to my vessel," the captain answered placidly. He put the scales and the bag back in the chest and closed it in a satisfied way. "Plus a bit for bringing Trollocs down on me so I must run downriver in the night when there be shallows aplenty to pile me up."

"wʌɾ əbaʊt ði ʌðɝz?" ɹænd æskt. "wɪl jə teɪk ðɛm, tu? ðeɪ ʃʊɾə ɹitʃt ðə ɹɪvɝ baɪ naʊ, əɹ ðeɪ sun wɪl, ən ðəl si ðət læntɝn ɑn jəɹ mæst."

"What about the others?" Rand asked. "Will you take them, too? They should have reached the river by now, or they soon will, and they'll see that lantern on your mast."

kæptən doʊmənz aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. "hæpən jə θɪŋk wi bi stændɪŋ stɪl, mæn? fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi, wi bi θɹi, fɔɹ maɪlz daʊnɹɪvɝ fɹəm wɛɹ jə keɪm əbɔɹd. tʃɹɑləks meɪk ðoʊz fɛloʊz pʊt ðɛɹ bæks ɪndə ði ɔɹz - ðeɪ noʊ tʃɹɑləks bɛɾɝ ðən ðeɪ laɪk - ən ðə kɝən hɛlps, tu. bʌɾ ɪt meɪks noʊ nɛvɝmaɪnd. aɪd noʊ pʊɾ ɪn əɡɛn tənaɪɾ ɪf maɪ oʊld ɡɹændmʌðɝ wɑz ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk. aɪ meɪ noʊ pʊɾ ɪn əɡɛn əɾ ɔl əntɪl aɪ ɹitʃ waɪtbɹɪdʒ. aɪv hæd maɪ fɪl ə tʃɹɑləks dɔɡɪŋ maɪ hilz lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ tənaɪt, ən əl əv noʊ mɔɹ kən aɪ hɛlp ɪt."

Captain Domon's eyebrows rose in surprise. "Happen you think we be standing still, man? Fortune prick me, we be three, four miles downriver from where you came aboard. Trollocs make those fellows put their backs into the oars - they know Trollocs better than they like - and the current helps, too. But it makes no nevermind. I'd no put in again tonight if my old grandmother was on the riverbank. I may no put in again at all until I reach Whitebridge. I've had my fill of Trollocs dogging my heels long before tonight, and I'll have no more can I help it."

tɑm lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪntʃɹəstɪdli. "ju hæv hæɾ ɪnkaʊntɝz wɪð tʃɹɑləks bɪfɔɹ? leɪtli?"

Thom leaned forward interestedly. "You have had encounters with Trollocs before? Lately?"

doʊmən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, aɪɪŋ tɑm nɛɹoʊli, bʌt wən i spoʊk i mɪɹli saʊndəd dɪsɡʌstəd. "aɪ wɪntɝɾ ɪn sɑldɑiə, mæn. nɑt maɪ tʃɔɪs, bʌt ðə ɹɪvɝ fɹoʊz ɝli ən ði aɪs bɹoʊk ʌp leɪt. ðeɪ seɪ jə kən si ðə blaɪt fɹəm ðə haɪəs taʊɝz ɪn mɛɹədɑn, bʌɾ aɪv noʊ maɪn fəɹ ðæt. aɪv bɪn ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ, ən ðəɹ ɔlweɪz bi tɔk ə tʃɹɑləks ətækɪŋ ə fɑɹm əɹ ðə laɪk. ðɪs wɪntɝ pæst, ðoʊ, ðəɹ bi fɑɹmz bɝnɪŋ ɛvɹi naɪt. aɪ, ən hoʊl vɪlədʒəz, tu, bɪtaɪmz. ðeɪ ivən keɪm ɹaɪɾ ʌp tə ðə sɪɾi wɔlz. ən ɪf ðət noʊ bi bæɾ ɪnʌf, ðə pipəl bi ɔl seɪɪŋ ɪt mɛn ðə dɑɹk wʌn bi stɝɪŋ, ðət ðə læs deɪz bi kʌm." hi ɡeɪv ə ʃɪvɝ, ən skɹætʃt əɾ ɪz hɛɾ əz ɪf ðə θɔt meɪɾ ɪz skælp ɪtʃ. "aɪ kən noʊ weɪt tə ɡɛt bæk wɛɹ pipəl θɪŋk tʃɹɑləks bi dʒʌs teɪlz, ðə stɔɹiz aɪ tɛl bi tʃɹævəlɝz laɪz."

Domon hesitated, eyeing Thom narrowly, but when he spoke he merely sounded disgusted. "I wintered in Saldaea, man. Not my choice, but the river froze early and the ice broke up late. They say you can see the Blight from the highest towers in Maradon, but I've no mind for that. I've been there before, and there always be talk of Trollocs attacking a farm or the like. This winter past, though, there be farms burning every night. Aye, and whole villages, too, betimes. They even came right up to the city walls. And if that no be bad enough, the people be all saying it meant the Dark One be stirring, that the Last Days be come." He gave a shiver, and scratched at his head as if the thought made his scalp itch. "I can no wait to get back where people think Trollocs be just tales, the stories I tell be traveler's lies."

ɹænd stɑp lɪsnɪŋ. hi stɛɹɾ ət ði ɑpəzət wɔl ən θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz. ɪt hɑɹdli simd ɹaɪt fəɹ ɪm tə bi seɪf ɑn ðə spɹeɪ waɪl ðeɪ wɝ stɪl bæk ðəɹ ɪn ðə naɪt sʌmwɛɹ. ðə kæptənz kæbən dɪd nɑt sim soʊ kʌmftəɹbəl əz bɪfɔɹ.

Rand stopped listening. He stared at the opposite wall and thought about Egwene and the others. It hardly seemed right for him to be safe on the Spray while they were still back there in the night somewhere. The captain's cabin did not seem so comfortable as before.

hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd wən tɑm pʊld ɪm tə hɪz fit. ðə ɡlimən pʊʃt mæt ən ɪm təwɔɹd ðə læɾɝ wɪð əpɑlədʒiz oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ tə kæptən doʊmən fəɹ ðə kʌntʃɹi laʊts. ɹænd klaɪmd ʌp wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd.

He was surprised when Thom pulled him to his feet. The gleeman pushed Mat and him toward the ladder with apologies over his shoulder to Captain Domon for the country louts. Rand climbed up without a word.

wʌns ðeɪ wɝ ɑn dɛk tɑm lʊkt ɝaʊn kwɪkli tə meɪk ʃʊɹ i wəd nɑt bi oʊvɝhɝd, ðən ɡɹaʊld, "aɪ cʊɾə ɡɑɾən əs pæsədʒ fəɹ ə fju sɔŋz ən stɔɹiz ɪf jə tu hædn bɪn soʊ kwɪk tə ʃoʊ sɪlvɝ."

Once they were on deck Thom looked around quickly to make sure he would not be overheard, then growled, "I could have gotten us passage for a few songs and stories if you two hadn't been so quick to show silver."

"aɪm nɑt soʊ ʃʊɹ," mæt sɛd. "hi saʊndəd sɪɹiəs əbaʊt θɹoʊɪŋ əs ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ tə mi."

"I'm not so sure," Mat said. "He sounded serious about throwing us in the river to me."

ɹænd wɔk sloʊli tə ðə ɹeɪl ən lin əɡɛnst ɪt, stɛɹɪŋ bæk ʌp ðə naɪt-ʃɹaʊɾɪd ɹɪvɝ. hi kəd nɑt si ɛniθɪŋ bʌt blæk, nɑɾ ivən ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk. æftɝ ə mɪnət tɑm pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt muv.

Rand walked slowly to the rail and leaned against it, staring back up the night-shrouded river. He could not see anything but black, not even the riverbank. After a minute Thom put a hand on his shoulder, but he did not move.

"ðɛɹ ɪzən ɛniθɪŋ jə kən du, læd. bɪsaɪdz, ðəɹ laɪkli seɪf wɪð ðə . . . wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn baɪ ðɪs taɪm. kən jə θɪŋk ʌv ɛni bɛɾɝ ðən ðoʊz tu fəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə lɑɾ ə ðɛm klɪɹ?"

"There isn't anything you can do, lad. Besides, they're likely safe with the . . . with Moiraine and Lan by this time. Can you think of any better than those two for getting the lot of them clear?"

"aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə tɔk əɹ aʊɾ ə kʌmɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd.

"I tried to talk her out of coming," Rand said.

"ju dɪd wʌt jə kʊd, læd. noʊ wʌn kəɾ æsk mɔɹ."

"You did what you could, lad. No one could ask more."

"aɪ toʊld əɹ aɪd teɪk kɛɹ ə hɝ. aɪ ʃʊɾə tʃɹaɪd hɑɹɾɝ." ðə kɹik ə ðə swips ən ðə hʌm ə ðə ɹɪɡɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪn meɪɾ ə mɔɹnfəl tun. "aɪ ʃʊɾə tʃɹaɪd hɑɹɾɝ," hi wɪspɝd.

"I told her I'd take care of her. I should have tried harder." The creak of the sweeps and the hum of the rigging in the wind made a mournful tune. "I should have tried harder," he whispered.


tʃæptɝ twɛntiwʌn


CHAPTER 21

lɪsən tə ðə wɪnd


Listen to the Wind

sʌnɹaɪz kɹipɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ ɑɹɪnɛl faʊn ɪts weɪ ɪndə ðə hɑloʊ nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk wɛɹ nɪneɪiv sæt wɪð əɹ bæk əɡɛns ðə tʃɹʌŋk ʌv ə jʌŋ oʊk, bɹiðɪŋ ðə dip bɹɛθ ə slip. hɝ hɔɹs slɛpt, tu, hɛd daʊn ən lɛɡz spɹæəld ɪn ðə mænɝ ə hɔɹsəz. ðə ɹeɪnz wɝ ɹæpt ɝaʊn əɹ ɹɪst. əz sʌnlaɪt fɛl ɑn ðə hɔɹsəz aɪlɪdz, ði ænəməl oʊpən ɪts aɪz ən ɹeɪzd ɪts hɛd, dʒɝkɪŋ ðə ɹeɪnz. nɪneɪiv keɪm əweɪk wɪð ə stɑɹt.

Sunrise creeping across the River Arinelle found its way into the hollow not far from the riverbank where Nynaeve sat with her back against the trunk of a young oak, breathing the deep breath of sleep. Her horse slept, too, head down and legs spraddled in the manner of horses. The reins were wrapped around her wrist. As sunlight fell on the horse's eyelids, the animal opened its eyes and raised its head, jerking the reins. Nynaeve came awake with a start.

fəɹ ə moʊmənt ʃi stɛɹd, wʌndɝɪŋ wɛɹ ʃi wɑz, ðən stɛɹɾ ɝaʊn ivən mɔɹ waɪldli wən ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd. bʌt ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli ðə tʃɹiz, ən əɹ hɔɹs, ən ə kɑɹpəɾ ʌv oʊld, dʒɹaɪ livz əkɹɔs ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə hɑloʊ. ɪn ðə dipəs dɪmnəs, səm ə læs jɪɹz ʃæɾoʊʃhænd mʌʃɹumz meɪd ɹɪŋz ɑn ə fɔlən lɔɡ.

For a moment she stared, wondering where she was, then stared around even more wildly when she remembered. But there were only the trees, and her horse, and a carpet of old, dry leaves across the bottom of the hollow. In the deepest dimness, some of last year's shadowshand mushrooms made rings on a fallen log.

"ðə laɪt pɹəzɝv ju, wʊmən," ʃi mɝmɝd, sæɡɪŋ bæk, "ɪf jə kæn steɪ əweɪk wʌn naɪt." ʃi əntaɪd ðə ɹeɪnz ən məsɑʒd əɹ ɹɪst əz ʃi stʊd. "ju cʊɾə əweɪkən ɪn ə tʃɹɑlɑk kʊkpɑt."

"The Light preserve you, woman," she murmured, sagging back, "if you can't stay awake one night." She untied the reins and massaged her wrist as she stood. "You could have awakened in a Trolloc cookpot."

ðə dɛd livz ɹʌsəld əz ʃi klaɪm tə ðə lɪp ə ðə hɑloʊ ən pipt oʊvɝ. noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə hændfʊl ʌv æʃ tʃɹiz stʊd bɪtwin əɹ ən ðə ɹɪvɝ. ðɛɹ fɪʃɝd bɑɹk ən bɛɹ bɹæntʃəz meɪɾ əm sim dɛd. bɪɑnd, ðə waɪd blu-ɡɹin wɔɾɝ floʊd baɪ. ɛmpti. ɛmpti ʌv ɛniθɪŋ. skæɾɝd klʌmps ʌv ɛvɝɡɹinz, wɪloʊz ən fɹz, dɑɾəd ðə fɑɹ bæŋk, ən ðəɹ sim tə bi fjuɝ tʃɹiz ɔltəɡɛðɝ ðən ɑn əɹ saɪd. ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn əɹ ɛni ʌv ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz wɝ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ, ðeɪ wɝ wɛl hɪɾən. ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən ðeɪ hæd tə hæv kɹɔst, əɹ tʃɹaɪd tə kɹɔs, ɪn saɪɾ ʌv wɛɹ ʃi wɑz. ðeɪ kəd bi ɛniwɛɹ tɛn maɪlz ʌpɹɪvɝ əɹ daʊn. ɪf ðəɹ əlaɪv əɾ ɔl, æftɝ læs naɪt.

The dead leaves rustled as she climbed to the lip of the hollow and peeped over. No more than a handful of ash trees stood between her and the river. Their fissured bark and bare branches made them seem dead. Beyond, the wide blue-green water flowed by. Empty. Empty of anything. Scattered clumps of evergreens, willows and firs, dotted the far bank, and there seemed to be fewer trees altogether than on her side. If Moiraine or any of the younglings were over there, they were well hidden. Of course, there was no reason they had to have crossed, or tried to cross, in sight of where she was. They could be anywhere ten miles upriver or down. If they're alive at all, after last night.

æŋɡɹi wɪð hɝsɛlf fəɹ θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi, ʃi slɪd bæk daʊn ɪndə ðə hɑloʊ. nɑɾ ivən wɪntɝnaɪt, əɹ ðə bæɾəl bɪfɔɹ ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, hæd pɹipɛɹɾ əɹ fəɹ læs naɪt, fəɹ ðət θɪŋ, mɑʃəɾɝ. ɔl ðət fɹæntɪk ɡæləpɪŋ, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ɛniwʌn ɛls wɑz stɪl əlaɪv, wʌndɝɪŋ wən ʃi wɑz gɑnə kʌm feɪs-tə-feɪs wɪð ə feɪd, əɹ tʃɹɑləks. ʃi hæd hɝd tʃɹɑləks ɡɹoʊlɪŋ ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ən ðə kwɪvɝɪŋ ʃɹiks ə tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹnz hæd tʃɪld əɹ dipɝ ðən ðə wɪn ɛvɝ kʊd, bʌɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ðət fɝst ɪnkaʊntɝ ɪn ðə ɹuənz ʃi sɔ tʃɹɑləks oʊnli wʌns, ən ðət wʌns ʃi wɑz aʊtsaɪd. tɛn əɹ soʊ ʌv əm sim tə spɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡɹaʊnd nɑt θɝɾi spænz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, baʊndɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əɹ ɑn ði ɪnstənt, haʊlɪŋ ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ, bɹændɪʃɪŋ hʊkt kætʃpoʊlz. jɛɾ əz ʃi pʊld əɹ hɔɹs ɝaʊnd, ðeɪ fɛl saɪlənt, lɪftɪŋ mʌzəlz tə snɪf ət ði ɛɹ. ʃi wɑtʃt, tu əstɑnɪʃt tə ɹʌn, əz ðeɪ tɝn ðɛɹ bæks ən vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə naɪt. ən ðət hæd bɪn ðə moʊs fɹaɪɾənɪŋ ʌv ɔl.

Angry with herself for thinking of the possibility, she slid back down into the hollow. Not even Winternight, or the battle before Shadar Logoth, had prepared her for last night, for that thing, Mashadar. All that frantic galloping, wondering if anyone else was still alive, wondering when she was going to come face-to-face with a Fade, or Trollocs. She had heard Trollocs growling and shouting in the distance, and the quivering shrieks of Trolloc horns had chilled her deeper than the wind ever could, but aside from that first encounter in the ruins she saw Trollocs only once, and that once she was outside. Ten or so of them seemed to spring out of the ground not thirty spans in front of her, bounding toward her on the instant, howling and shouting, brandishing hooked catchpoles. Yet as she pulled her horse around, they fell silent, lifting muzzles to sniff at the air. She watched, too astonished to run, as they turned their backs and vanished into the night. And that had been the most frightening of all.

"ðeɪ noʊ ðə smɛl ə hu ðeɪ wɑnt," ʃi toʊld əɹ hɔɹs, stændɪŋ ɪn ðə hɑloʊ, "æn ɪts nɑt mi. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz ɹaɪt, ɪt simz, ðə ʃɛpɝɾ ə ðə naɪt swɑloʊ hɝ ʌp."

"They know the smell of who they want," she told her horse, standing in the hollow, "and it is not me. The Aes Sedai is right, it seems, the Shepherd of the Night swallow her up."

ɹitʃɪŋ ə dɪsɪʒən, ʃi sɛɾ aʊt daʊnɹɪvɝ, liɾɪŋ əɹ hɔɹs. ʃi muv sloʊli, kipɪŋ ə wɛɹi wɑtʃ ɑn ðə fɔɹəst ɝaʊn hɝ; dʒʌs kəz ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd nɑt wɑntəɾ əɹ læs naɪt dɪd nɑt min ðeɪ wəd lɛɾ əɹ ɡoʊ ɪf ʃi stʌmbəld ɑn əm əɡɛn. əz mʌtʃ ətɛnʃən əz ʃi ɡeɪv ðə wʊdz, ʃi ɡeɪv ivən mɔɹ tə ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ. ɪf ði ʌðɝz hæd kɹɔs bɪloʊ hɝ dʊɹɪŋ ðə naɪt, ʃi ʃəd si səm saɪnz ə ðɛm, saɪnz ʃi maɪt mɪs fɹəm hɔɹsbæk. ʃi maɪɾ ivən kʌm ɑn əm ɔl stɪl ɑn ðɪs saɪd. ɪf ʃi faʊnd niðɝ, ðə ɹɪvɝ wəd teɪk əɹ tə waɪtbɹɪdʒ ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹoʊd fɹəm waɪtbɹɪdʒ tə keɪɛmlɪn, ən ɔl ðə weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɪf nid bi.

Reaching a decision, she set out downriver, leading her horse. She moved slowly, keeping a wary watch on the forest around her; just because the Trollocs had not wanted her last night did not mean they would let her go if she stumbled on them again. As much attention as she gave the woods, she gave even more to the ground in front of her. If the others had crossed below her during the night, she should see some signs of them, signs she might miss from horseback. She might even come on them all still on this side. If she found neither, the river would take her to Whitebridge eventually, and there was a road from Whitebridge to Caemlyn, and all the way to Tar Valon if need be.

ðə pɹɑspɛkt wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɪnʌf tə dɔn hɝ. bɪfɔɹ ðɪs ʃi hæd bɪn noʊ fɝðɝ fɹəm ɛmənz fil ðən hæd ðə bɔɪz. tɛɹən fɛɹi hæd sim stʃɹeɪnʒ tə hɝ; bɛɹlən wʊɾə hæɾ əɹ stɛɹɪŋ ɪn wʌndɝ ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt bɪn soʊ sɛɾ ɑn faɪndɪŋ ɛɡwin ən ði ʌðɝz. bʌt ʃi əlaʊd nʌn ə ðət tə wikən əɹ ɹizɑlv. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ʃi wəd faɪn ɛɡwin ən ðə bɔɪz. əɹ faɪn ə weɪ tə meɪk ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ænsɝ fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ hæd hæpən tə ðɛm. wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ, ʃi vaʊd.

The prospect was almost enough to daunt her. Before this she had been no further from Emond's Field than had the boys. Taren Ferry had seemed strange to her; Baerlon would have had her staring in wonder if she had not been so set on finding Egwene and the others. But she allowed none of that to weaken her resolve. Sooner or later she would find Egwene and the boys. Or find a way to make the Aes Sedai answer for whatever had happened to them. One or the other, she vowed.

əɾ ɪntɝvəlz ʃi faʊn tʃɹæks, plɛnti ʌv ðɛm, bʌt juʒəwəli hɝ bɛst ɛfɝts kəd nɑt seɪ wɛðɝ ðoʊz u meɪɾ əm hæd bɪn sɝtʃɪŋ əɹ tʃeɪsɪŋ əɹ pɝsud. səm hæd bɪn meɪd baɪ buts ðət cʊɾə bɪlɔŋ tə hjumənz əɹ tʃɹɑləks iðɝ wʌn. ʌðɝz wɝ hʊfpɹɪns, laɪk ɡoʊts əɹ ɑksən; ðoʊz wɝ tʃɹɑləks fəɹ ʃʊɹ. bʌt nɛvɝ ə klɪɹ saɪn ðət ʃi kəd dɛfənətli seɪ keɪm fɹəm ɛni ʌv ðoʊz ʃi sɔt.

At intervals she found tracks, plenty of them, but usually her best efforts could not say whether those who made them had been searching or chasing or pursued. Some had been made by boots that could have belonged to humans or Trollocs either one. Others were hoofprints, like goats or oxen; those were Trollocs for sure. But never a clear sign that she could definitely say came from any of those she sought.

ʃi hæd kʌvɝd pɝhæps fɔɹ maɪlz wən ðə wɪn bɹɔɾ əɹ ə wɪf ʌv wʊdzmoʊk. ɪt keɪm fɹəm fɝðɝ daʊnɹɪvɝ, ən nɑt tu fɑɹ, ʃi θɔt. ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ taɪɪŋ əɹ hɔɹs tə ə fɝ tʃɹi, wɛl bæk fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ ɪn ə smɔl, θɪk stæn ʌv ɛvɝɡɹinz ðət ʃəd kip ði ænəməl hɪɾən. ðə smoʊk kəd min tʃɹɑləks, bʌt ði oʊnli weɪ tə faɪn aʊt wɑz tə lʊk. ʃi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðə jus tʃɹɑləks maɪt bi meɪkɪŋ ʌv ə faɪɝ.

She had covered perhaps four miles when the wind brought her a whiff of woodsmoke. It came from further downriver, and not too far, she thought. She hesitated only a moment before tying her horse to a fir tree, well back from the river in a small, thick stand of evergreens that should keep the animal hidden. The smoke could mean Trollocs, but the only way to find out was to look. She tried not to think about the use Trollocs might be making of a fire.

kɹaʊtʃɪŋ, ʃi slɪp fɹəm tʃɹi tə tʃɹi, mɛntəli kɝsɪŋ ðə skɝts ʃi hæd tə hoʊld ʌp aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ. dʒɹɛsəz wɝ nɑt meɪd fəɹ stɔkɪŋ. ðə saʊn ʌv ə hɔɹs sloʊd hɝ, ən wən ʃi faɪnəli pɪɹd kɔʃəsli ɝaʊn ðə tʃɹʌŋk ʌv ən æʃ, ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz dɪsmaʊntɪŋ fɹəm ɪz blæk wɔɹhɔɹs ɪn ə smɔl klɪɹɪŋ ɑn ðə bæŋk. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sæɾ ɑn ə lɔɡ bɪsaɪɾ ə smɔl faɪɝ wɛɹ ə kɛɾəl ʌv wɔɾɝ wɑz dʒʌs kʌmɪŋ tə ə bɔɪl. hɝ waɪt mɛɹ bɹaʊz bɪhaɪn əɹ əmʌŋ spɑɹs widz. nɪneɪiv ɹɪmeɪnd wɛɹ ʃi wɑz.

Crouching, she slipped from tree to tree, mentally cursing the skirts she had to hold up out of the way. Dresses were not made for stalking. The sound of a horse slowed her, and when she finally peered cautiously around the trunk of an ash, the Warder was dismounting from his black warhorse in a small clearing on the bank. The Aes Sedai sat on a log beside a small fire where a kettle of water was just coming to a boil. Her white mare browsed behind her among sparse weeds. Nynaeve remained where she was.

"ðeɪ ɑɹ ɔl ɡɔn," læn ənaʊnst ɡɹɪmli. "fɔɹ hæfmən stɑɹɾəd saʊθ əbaʊt tu aʊɝz bɪfɔɹ dɔn, əz nɪɹ əz aɪ kən tɛl - ðeɪ doʊn liv mʌtʃ tʃɹeɪs bɪhaɪnd - bʌt ðə tʃɹɑləks əv vænɪʃt. ivən ðə kɔɹpsəz, ən tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ nɑt noʊn fəɹ kæɹiɪŋ ɔf ðɛɹ dɛd. ənlɛs ðəɹ hʌŋɡɹi."

"They are all gone," Lan announced grimly. "Four Halfmen started south about two hours before dawn, as near as I can tell - they don't leave much trace behind - but the Trollocs have vanished. Even the corpses, and Trollocs are not known for carrying off their dead. Unless they're hungry."

mɔɪɹeɪn tɔst ə hændfʊl ə sʌmθɪŋ ɪndə ðə bɔɪlɪŋ wɔɾɝ ən muv ðə kɛɾəl fɹəm ðə faɪɝ. "wʌn kəɾ ɔlweɪz hoʊp ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn bæk ɪndə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ən bɪn kənsum baɪ ɪt, bʌt ðət wəd bi tu mʌtʃ tə wɪʃ fɔɹ."

Moiraine tossed a handful of something into the boiling water and moved the kettle from the fire. "One could always hope they had gone back into Shadar Logoth and been consumed by it, but that would be too much to wish for."

ðə dɪlɪʃəs oʊɾɝ ə ti dʒɹɪftəd tə nɪneɪiv. laɪt, doʊn lɛt maɪ stʌmək ɡɹʌmbəl.

The delicious odor of tea drifted to Nynaeve. Light, don't let my stomach grumble.

"ðɛɹ wɑz noʊ klɪɹ saɪn ə ðə bɔɪz, əɹ ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz. ðə tʃɹæks ɑɹ tu mʌɾəld tə tɛl ɛniθɪŋ." ɪn əɹ kənsilmənt, nɪneɪiv smaɪld; ðə wɔɹɾɝz feɪljɝ wɑz ə slaɪt vɪndəkeɪʃən ə hɝ oʊn. "bʌt ðɪs ʌðɝ ɪz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, mɔɪɹeɪn," læn wɛn ɑn, fɹaʊnɪŋ. hi weɪvd əweɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz ɔfɝ ə ti ən bɪɡæn mɑɹtʃɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝ, wʌn hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt ən ɪz kloʊk tʃeɪnʒɪŋ kʌlɝz əz i tɝnd. "aɪ kəɾ æksɛp tʃɹɑləks ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ivən ə hʌnʒɹəd tʃɹɑləks. bʌt ðɪs? ðəɹ mʌst əv bɪn ɔlmoʊst ə θaʊzən ɪn ðə hʌn fəɹ əs jɛstɝdeɪ."

"There was no clear sign of the boys, or any of the others. The tracks are too muddled to tell anything." In her concealment, Nynaeve smiled; the Warder's failure was a slight vindication of her own. "But this other is important, Moiraine," Lan went on, frowning. He waved away the Aes Sedai's offer of tea and began marching up and down in front of the fire, one hand on his sword hilt and his cloak changing colors as he turned. "I could accept Trollocs in the Two Rivers, even a hundred Trollocs. But this? There must have been almost a thousand in the hunt for us yesterday."

"wi wɝ vɛɹi lʌki ðət nɑɾ ɔl steɪd tə sɝtʃ ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl mʌst əv daʊɾɪd wi wəd haɪd ðɛɹ, bʌt ðeɪ ɔlsoʊ fɪɹd tə ɹɪtɝn tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl livɪŋ ivən ðə slaɪɾəst tʃæns ənkʌvɝd. ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑz nɛvɝ ə liniən mæstɝ."

"We were very lucky that not all stayed to search Shadar Logoth. The Myrddraal must have doubted we would hide there, but they also feared to return to Shayol Ghul leaving even the slightest chance uncovered. The Dark One was never a lenient master."

"doʊn tʃɹaɪ tə ɪveɪɾ ɪt. jə noʊ wʌɾ aɪm seɪɪŋ. ɪf ðoʊz θaʊzənd wɝ hɪɹ tə bi sɛn ɪndə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, waɪ wɝ ðeɪ nɑt? ðəɹ ɪz oʊnli wʌn ænsɝ. ðeɪ wɝ sɛn oʊnli æftɝ wi kɹɔs ðə tɛɹən, wən ɪt wɑz noʊn ðət wʌn mɹdʒɹɑl ən ə hʌnʒɹəd tʃɹɑləks wɝ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɪnʌf. haʊ? haʊ wɝ ðeɪ sɛnt? ɪf ə θaʊzən tʃɹɑləks kən bi bɹɔt soʊ fɑɹ saʊθ fɹəm ðə blaɪt, soʊ kwɪkli, ənsin - nɑt tə mɛnʃən biɪŋ teɪkən ɔf ðə seɪm weɪ - kən tɛn θaʊzən bi sɛn ɪndə ðə hɑɹɾ ə sɑldɑiə, əɹ ɝæfəl, əɹ ʃaɪnɝ? ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz kəd bi oʊvɝɹʌn ɪn ə jɪɹ."

"Don't try to evade it. You know what I am saying. If those thousand were here to be sent into the Two Rivers, why were they not? There is only one answer. They were sent only after we crossed the Taren, when it was known that one Myrddraal and a hundred Trollocs were no longer enough. How? How were they sent? If a thousand Trollocs can be brought so far south from the Blight, so quickly, unseen - not to mention being taken off the same way - can ten thousand be sent into the heart of Saldaea, or Arafel, or Shienar? The Borderlands could be overrun in a year."

"ðə hoʊl wɝld wɪl bi oʊvɝɹʌn ɪn faɪv ɪf wi də nɑt faɪn ðoʊz bɔɪz," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd sɪmpli. "ðə kwɛstʃən wɝiz mi, ɔlsoʊ, bʌɾ aɪ hæv noʊ ænsɝz. ðə weɪz ɑɹ kloʊzd, ən ðəɹ əz nɑt bɪn ən ɛɛs sədaɪ paʊɝfəl ɪnʌf tə tʃɹævəl sɪns ðə taɪm ə mædnəs. ənlɛs wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɪz lus - ðə laɪt sɛn ɪts nɑt soʊ, jɛɾ əɹ ɛvɝ - ðəɹ ɪz stɪl noʊ wʌn u kæn. ɪn ɛni keɪs, aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ɔl ðə fɔɹseɪkən təɡɛðɝ kəd muv ə θaʊzən tʃɹɑləks. lɛɾ əs dil wɪð ðə pɹɑbləmz ðət feɪs əs hɪɹ ən naʊ; ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls mʌst weɪt."

"The whole world will be overrun in five if we do not find those boys," Moiraine said simply. "The question worries me, also, but I have no answers. The Ways are closed, and there has not been an Aes Sedai powerful enough to Travel since the Time of Madness. Unless one of the Forsaken is loose - the Light send it is not so, yet or ever - there is still no one who can. In any case, I do not think all the Forsaken together could move a thousand Trollocs. Let us deal with the problems that face us here and now; everything else must wait."

"ðə bɔɪz." ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə kwɛstʃən.

"The boys." It was not a question.

"aɪ hæv nɑt bɪn aɪɾəl waɪl jə wɝ əweɪ. wʌn ɪz əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ, ən əlaɪv. əz fəɹ ði ʌðɝz, ðəɹ wɑz ə feɪn tʃɹeɪs daʊnɹɪvɝ, bʌɾ ɪt feɪɾəd əweɪ əz aɪ faʊn ɪt. ðə bɑn hæd bɪn bɹoʊkən fəɹ aʊɝz bɪfɔɹ aɪ bɪɡæn maɪ sɝtʃ."

"I have not been idle while you were away. One is across the river, and alive. As for the others, there was a faint trace downriver, but it faded away as I found it. The bond had been broken for hours before I began my search."

kɹaʊtʃt bɪhaɪn əɹ tʃɹi, nɪneɪiv fɹaʊn ɪn pʌzəlmənt.

Crouched behind her tree, Nynaeve frowned in puzzlement.

læn stɑpt ɪz peɪsɪŋ. "ju θɪŋk ðə hæfmən hɛɾɪŋ saʊθ əv ðɛm?"

Lan stopped his pacing. "You think the Halfmen heading south have them?"

"pɝhæps." mɔɪɹeɪn pɔɹd hɝsɛlf ə kʌp ə ti bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. "bʌɾ əl nɑɾ ədmɪt ðə pɑsəbɪləɾi ʌv əm biɪŋ dɛd. aɪ kænɑt. aɪ dɛɹ nɑt. jə noʊ haʊ mʌtʃ ɪz ət steɪk. aɪ mʌst əv ðoʊz jʌŋ mɛn. ðət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl wɪl hʌn ðɛm, aɪ ɪkspɛkt. ɑpəzɪʃən fɹəm wɪðɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ, ivən fɹəm ði æmɪɝlɪn sit, aɪ æksɛpt. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wɪl æksɛpt oʊnli wʌn səluʃən. bʌt. . . ." sʌɾənli ʃi pʊɾ əɹ kʌp daʊn ən sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ. "ɪf jə wɑtʃ ðə wʊlf tu hɑɹd," ʃi mʌɾɝd, "ə maʊs wɪl baɪt jə ɑn ði æŋkəl." ən ʃi lʊkt ɹaɪɾ ət ðə tʃɹi bɪhaɪnd wɪtʃ nɪneɪiv wɑz haɪɾɪŋ. "mɪstʃɹəs ɑlmɹə, jə meɪ kʌm aʊt naʊ, ɪf jə wɪʃ."

"Perhaps." Moiraine poured herself a cup of tea before going on. "But I will not admit the possibility of them being dead. I cannot. I dare not. You know how much is at stake. I must have those young men. That Shayol Ghul will hunt them, I expect. Opposition from within the White Tower, even from the Amyrlin Seat, I accept. There are always Aes Sedai who will accept only one solution. But. . . ." Suddenly she put her cup down and sat up straight, grimacing. "If you watch the wolf too hard," she muttered, "a mouse will bite you on the ankle." And she looked right at the tree behind which Nynaeve was hiding. "Mistress al'Meara, you may come out now, if you wish."

nɪneɪiv skɹæmbəl tə hɝ fit, heɪstəli dʌstɪŋ dɛd livz fɹəm əɹ dʒɹɛs. læn hæd spʌn tə feɪs ðə tʃɹi əz sun əz mɔɪɹeɪnz aɪz muvd; hɪz sɔɹd wɑz ɪn ɪz hæn bɪfɔɹ ʃi fɪnɪʃt spikɪŋ nɪneɪivz neɪm. naʊ hi ʃiðd ɪɾ əɡɛn wɪð mɔɹ fɔɹs ðən wɑz stʃɹɪkli nɛsəsɛɹi. hɪz feɪs wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz ɪkspɹɛʃənləs əz ɛvɝ, bʌt nɪneɪiv θɔt ðəɹ wɑz ə tʌtʃ ə ʃəɡɹɪn əbaʊt ðə sɛɾ ə hɪz maʊθ. ʃi fɛlt ə stæb ə sæɾəsfækʃən; ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæd nɑt noʊn ʃi wɑz ðɛɹ, ət list.

Nynaeve scrambled to her feet, hastily dusting dead leaves from her dress. Lan had spun to face the tree as soon as Moiraine's eyes moved; his sword was in his hand before she finished speaking Nynaeve's name. Now he sheathed it again with more force than was strictly necessary. His face was almost as expressionless as ever, but Nynaeve thought there was a touch of chagrin about the set of his mouth. She felt a stab of satisfaction; the Warder had not known she was there, at least.

sæɾəsfækʃən læstəɾ oʊnli ə moʊmənt, ðoʊ. ʃi fæsən əɹ aɪz ɑn mɔɪɹeɪn ən wɔk təwɔɹɾ əɹ pɝpəsfəli. ʃi wɑntəd tə ɹɪmeɪn koʊld ən kɑm, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs kwɪvɝd wɪð æŋɡɝ. "wʌɾ əv jə mɛʃt ɛɡwin ən ðə bɔɪz ɪn? wʌt fɪlθi ɛɛs sədaɪ plɑts ɑɹ jə plænɪŋ tə juz əm ɪn?"

Satisfaction lasted only a moment, though. She fastened her eyes on Moiraine and walked toward her purposefully. She wanted to remain cold and calm, but her voice quivered with anger. "What have you meshed Egwene and the boys in? What filthy Aes Sedai plots are you planning to use them in?"

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pɪkt ʌp əɹ kʌp ən kɑmli sɪpt əɹ ti. wən nɪneɪiv wɑz kloʊs, ðoʊ, læn pʊɾ aʊɾ ən ɑɹm tə bɑɹ əɹ weɪ. ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə bɹʌʃ ði əbstʃɹʌkʃən əsaɪd, ən wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd wən ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɑɹm muv noʊ mɔɹ ðən ən oʊk bɹæntʃ wəd hæv. ʃi wɑz nɑt fɹeɪl, bʌɾ ɪz mʌsəlz wɝ laɪk aɪɝn.

The Aes Sedai picked up her cup and calmly sipped her tea. When Nynaeve was close, though, Lan put out an arm to bar her way. She tried to brush the obstruction aside, and was surprised when the Warder's arm moved no more than an oak branch would have. She was not frail, but his muscles were like iron.

"ti?" mɔɪɹeɪn ɔfɝd.

"Tea?" Moiraine offered.

"noʊ, aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛni ti. aɪ wəd nɑt dʒɹɪŋk jəɹ ti ɪf aɪ wɑz daɪɪŋ ə θɝst. jə woʊn juz ɛni ɛmənz fil foʊk ɪn jəɹ dɝɾi ɛɛs sədaɪ skimz."

"No, I don't want any tea. I would not drink your tea if I was dying of thirst. You won't use any Emond's Field folk in your dirty Aes Sedai schemes."

"ju hæv vɛɹi lɪɾəl ɹum tə tɔk, wɪzdəm." mɔɪɹeɪn ʃoʊd mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəst ɪn əɹ hɑt ti ðən ɪn ɛniθɪŋ ʃi wɑz seɪɪŋ. "ju kən wil ðə wʌn paʊɝ jɝsɛlf, æftɝ ə fæʃən."

"You have very little room to talk, Wisdom." Moiraine showed more interest in her hot tea than in anything she was saying. "You can wield the One Power yourself, after a fashion."

nɪneɪiv pʊʃt ət lænz ɑɹm əɡɛn; ɪt stɪl dɪd nɑt muv, ən ʃi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɪt. "waɪ doʊn jə tʃɹaɪ kleɪmɪŋ aɪm ə tʃɹɑlɑk?"

Nynaeve pushed at Lan's arm again; it still did not move, and she decided to ignore it. "Why don't you try claiming I am a Trolloc?"

mɔɪɹeɪnz smaɪl wɑz soʊ noʊɪŋ ðət nɪneɪiv wɑntəd tə hɪt hɝ. "du jə θɪŋk aɪ kən stæn feɪs-tə-feɪs wɪð ə wʊmən u kən tʌtʃ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ən tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ivən ɪf oʊnli naʊ ən ðɛn, wɪθaʊt noʊɪŋ wʌt ʃi ɪz? dʒʌst əz jə sɛns ðə pətɛnʃəl ɪn ɛɡwin. haʊ dʒju θɪŋk aɪ nu jə wɝ bɪhaɪn ðət tʃɹi? ɪf aɪ hæd nɑt bɪn dɪstʃɹæktəd, aɪ wʊɾə noʊn ðə moʊmən jə keɪm kloʊs. jə sɝɾənli ɑɹ nɑɾ ə tʃɹɑlɑk, fəɹ mi tə fil ði ivəl ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. soʊ wʌɾ aɪ sɛns, nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə, wɪzdəm ʌv ɛmənz fild ən ənnoʊɪŋ wildɝ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ?"

Moiraine's smile was so knowing that Nynaeve wanted to hit her. "Do you think I can stand face-to-face with a woman who can touch the True Source and channel the One Power, even if only now and then, without knowing what she is? Just as you sensed the potential in Egwene. How do you think I knew you were behind that tree? If I had not been distracted, I would have known the moment you came close. You certainly are not a Trolloc, for me to feel the evil of the Dark One. So what did I sense, Nynaeve al'Meara, Wisdom of Emond's Field and unknowing wielder of the One Power?"

læn wɑz lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət nɪneɪiv ɪn ə weɪ ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk; sɝpɹaɪzd ən spɛkjələɾɪv, ɪt sim tə hɝ, ðoʊ nʌθɪŋ hæd tʃeɪnʒd əbaʊɾ ɪz feɪs bʌɾ ɪz aɪz. ɛɡwin wɑz spɛʃəl; ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz noʊn ðæt. ɛɡwin wəd meɪk ə faɪn wɪzdəm. ðəɹ wɝkɪŋ təɡɛðɝ, ʃi θɔt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊt mi ɔf bæləns. "aɪ woʊn lɪsən tə ɛni mɔɹ ə ðɪs. jə - "

Lan was looking down at Nynaeve in a way she did not like; surprised and speculative, it seemed to her, though nothing had changed about his face but his eyes. Egwene was special; she had always known that. Egwene would make a fine Wisdom. They're working together, she thought, trying to put me off balance. "I won't listen to any more of this. You - "

"ju mʌs lɪsən," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd fɝmli. "aɪ hæd maɪ səspɪʃənz ɪn ɛmənz fild ivən bɪfɔɹ aɪ mɛt ju. pipəl toʊl mi haʊ əpsɛt ðə wɪzdəm wɑz ðət ʃi hæd nɑt pɹɪdɪktɪd ðə hɑɹd wɪntɝ ən ðə leɪtnəs ə spɹɪŋ. ðeɪ toʊl mi haʊ ɡʊd ʃi wɑz ət fɔɹtɛlɪŋ wɛðɝ, ət tɛlɪŋ ðə kɹɑps. ðeɪ toʊl mi haʊ wʌndɝfəl əɹ kjʊɹz wɝ, haʊ ʃi səmtaɪmz hild ɪnʒɝiz, ðət ʃʊɾə bɪn kɹɪpəlɪŋ, soʊ wɛl ðəɹ wɑz bɛɹli ə skɑɹ, ən nɑɾ ə lɪmp əɹ ə twɪnʒ. ði oʊnli ɪl wɝɾ aɪ hɝɾ əbaʊt jə wɑz fɹəm ə fju hu θɔt jə tu jʌŋ fəɹ ðə ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi, ən ðəɾ oʊnli stʃɹɛŋθən maɪ səspɪʃənz. soʊ mʌtʃ skɪl soʊ jʌŋ."

"You must listen," Moiraine said firmly. "I had my suspicions in Emond's Field even before I met you. People told me how upset the Wisdom was that she had not predicted the hard winter and the lateness of spring. They told me how good she was at foretelling weather, at telling the crops. They told me how wonderful her cures were, how she sometimes healed injuries, that should have been crippling, so well there was barely a scar, and not a limp or a twinge. The only ill word I heard about you was from a few who thought you too young for the responsibility, and that only strengthened my suspicions. So much skill so young."

"mɪstʃɹəs bæɹən tɔt mi wɛl." ʃi tʃɹaɪd lʊkɪŋ ət læn, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz stɪl meɪɾ əɹ ənkʌmftəɹbəl, soʊ ʃi sɛɾəld fəɹ stɛɹɪŋ oʊvɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz hɛɾ ət ðə ɹɪvɝ. haʊ dɛɹ ðə vɪlədʒ ɡɑsəp ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ən aʊtləndɝ! "hu sɛɾ aɪ wɑz tu jʌŋ?" ʃi dɪmændəd.

"Mistress Barran taught me well." She tried looking at Lan, but his eyes still made her uncomfortable, so she settled for staring over the Aes Sedai's head at the river. How dare the village gossip in front of an outlander! "Who said I was too young?" she demanded.

mɔɪɹeɪn smaɪld, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə bi daɪvɝɾɪd. "ənlaɪk moʊst wɪmən u kleɪm tə lɪsən tə ðə wɪnd, jə æktʃəli  kæn, səmtaɪmz. ɪts əz nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə wɪnd, ʌv ɪts ɪz ʌv ɛɹ ən ɪts ɪz nɑt sʌmθɪŋ jə niɾəd tə bi tɔt; ɪt wɑz bɔɹn ɪndə ju, dʒʌst əz ɪt wɑz bɔɹn ɪndə ɛɡwin. juv hæv lɝn tə hændəl ɪt, wɪtʃ ʃi stɪl əz tə lɝn. tu mɪnəts æftɝ aɪ keɪm feɪs-tə-feɪs wɪð ju, aɪ dʒju jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ haʊ aɪ sʌɾənli æsk jə ɪf jə wɝ ðə wɪzdəm? dʒju jə θɪŋk? ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃ jə fɹəm ɛni ʌðɝ pɹɪɾi jʌŋ wʊmən ɡɛɾɪŋ ɹɛɾi fəɹ fɛstəvəl. ivən lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ə jʌŋ wɪzdəm aɪ ɪkspɛktəd sʌmwʌn hæf əɡɛn jəɹ eɪdʒ."

Moiraine smiled, refusing to be diverted. "Unlike most women who claim to listen to the wind, you actually can, sometimes. Oh, it has nothing to do with the wind, of course. It is of Air and Water. It is not something you needed to be taught; it was born into you, just as it was born into Egwene. But you have learned to handle it, which she still has to learn. Two minutes after I came face-to-face with you, I knew. Do you remember how I suddenly asked you if you were the Wisdom? Why, do you think? There was nothing to distinguish you from any other pretty young woman getting ready for Festival. Even looking for a young Wisdom I expected someone half again your age."

nɪneɪiv ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət miɾɪŋ ɔl tu wɛl; ðɪs wʊmən, mɔɹ sɛlf-pəzɛs ðən ɛniwʌn ɪn ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl, ɪn ə dʒɹɛs mɔɹ bjuɾəfəl ðən ɛni ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, ədʒɹɛsɪŋ əɹ əz ə tʃaɪld. ðən mɔɪɹeɪn hæd sʌɾənli blɪŋkt əz ɪf sɝpɹaɪzd ən aʊɾ ʌv ə klɪɹ skaɪ æskt. . . .

Nynaeve remembered that meeting all too well; this woman, more self-possessed than anyone in the Women's Circle, in a dress more beautiful than any she had ever seen, addressing her as a child. Then Moiraine had suddenly blinked as if surprised and out of a clear sky asked. . . .

ʃi lɪk lɪps ɡɔn əbɹʌpli dʒɹaɪ. ðeɪ wɝ boʊθ lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ, ðə wɔɹɾɝz feɪs əz ənɹiɾəbəl əz ə stoʊn, ði ɛɛs sədaɪz sɪmpəθɛɾɪk jɛɾ ɪntɛnt. nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "noʊ! noʊ, ɪts ɪmpɑsəbəl. aɪ wəd noʊ. jə ɑɹ dʒʌs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃɹɪk mi, ən ɪɾəl nɑt wɝk."

She licked lips gone abruptly dry. They were both looking at her, the Warder's face as unreadable as a stone, the Aes Sedai's sympathetic yet intent. Nynaeve shook her head. "No! No, it's impossible. I would know. You are just trying to trick me, and it will not work."

"ʌv kɔɹs jə də nɑt noʊ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd suðɪŋli. "waɪ ʃəd jə ivən səspɛkt? ɔl ə jəɹ laɪf juv hɝɾ əbaʊt lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə wɪnd. ɪn ɛni keɪs, jə wəɾ əz sun ənaʊns tə ɔl ʌv ɛmənz fil ðət jə wɝ ə dɑɹkfɹɛn əz ədmɪt tə jɝsɛlf, ivən ɪn ðə dipəst ɹisɛsəz ə jəɹ maɪnd, ðət juv ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, əɹ ðə dʒɹɛɾɪd ɛɛs sədaɪ." əmjuzmən flɪɾɪd əkɹɔs mɔɪɹeɪnz feɪs. "bʌɾ aɪ kən tɛl jə haʊ ɪt bɪɡæn."

"Of course you do not know," Moiraine said soothingly. "Why should you even suspect? All of your life you have heard about listening to the wind. In any case, you would as soon announce to all of Emond's Field that you were a Darkfriend as admit to yourself, even in the deepest recesses of your mind, that you have anything to do with the One Power, or the dreaded Aes Sedai." Amusement flitted across Moiraine's face. "But I can tell you how it began."

"aɪ doʊnt wɑnə hɪɹ ɛni mɔɹ ə jəɹ laɪz," ʃi sɛd, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛn ɹaɪɾ ɑn.

"I don't want to hear any more of your lies," she said, but the Aes Sedai went right on.

"pɝhæps əz mʌtʃ əz eɪɾ əɹ tɛn jɪɹz əɡoʊ - ði eɪdʒ vɛɹiz, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz kʌmz jʌŋ - ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ jə wɑntəd mɔɹ ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ɪn ðə wɝld, sʌmθɪŋ jə niɾəd. ən jə ɡɑɾ ɪt. ə bɹæntʃ sʌɾənli fɔlɪŋ wɛɹ jə kəd pʊl jɝsɛlf aʊɾ ʌv ə pɑn ɪnstɛɾ ə dʒɹaʊnɪŋ. ə fɹɛnd, əɹ ə pɛt, ɡɛɾɪŋ wɛl wən ɛvɹiwʌn θɔt ðeɪ wəd daɪ.

"Perhaps as much as eight or ten years ago - the age varies, but always comes young - there was something you wanted more than anything else in the world, something you needed. And you got it. A branch suddenly falling where you could pull yourself out of a pond instead of drowning. A friend, or a pet, getting well when everyone thought they would die.

"ju fɛl nʌθɪŋ spɛʃəl ət ðə taɪm, bʌɾ ə wik əɹ tɛn deɪz leɪɾɝ jə hæd jəɹ fɝst ɹiækʃən tə tʌtʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. pɝhæps fivɝ ən tʃɪlz ðət keɪm ɑn sʌɾənli ən pʊt jə tə bɛd, ðən dɪsəpɪɹɾ æftɝ oʊnli ə fju aʊɝz. nʌn ə ðə ɹiækʃənz, ən ðeɪ vɛɹi, læsts mɔɹ ðən ə fju aʊɝz. hɛdeɪks ən nʌmnəs ən ɪɡzɪlɝeɪʃən ɔl mɪks təɡɛðɝ, ən jə teɪkɪŋ fulɪʃ tʃænsəz əɹ æktɪŋ ɡɪɾi. ə spɛl ə dɪzinəs, wən jə tʃɹɪpt ən stʌmbəld wɛnɛvɝ jə tʃɹaɪd tə muv, wən jə kəd nɑt seɪ ə sɛntəns wɪθaʊt jəɹ tʌŋ mæŋɡəlɪŋ hæf ðə wɝdz. ðəɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝz. dʒju ɹɪmɛmbɝ?"

"You felt nothing special at the time, but a week or ten days later you had your first reaction to touching the True Source. Perhaps fever and chills that came on suddenly and put you to bed, then disappeared after only a few hours. None of the reactions, and they vary, lasts more than a few hours. Headaches and numbness and exhilaration all mixed together, and you taking foolish chances or acting giddy. A spell of dizziness, when you tripped and stumbled whenever you tried to move, when you could not say a sentence without your tongue mangling half the words. There are others. Do you remember?"

nɪneɪiv sæt daʊn hɑɹɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd; hɝ lɛɡz wəd nɑt hoʊld əɹ ʌp. ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd, bʌt ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛɾ ɛniweɪ. ɪt hæd tə bi koʊɪnsɪɾəns. əɹ ɛls mɔɪɹeɪn hæɾ æsk mɔɹ kwɛstʃənz ɪn ɛmənz fil ðən ʃi hæd θɔt. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæɾ æskt ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni kwɛstʃənz. ɪt hæd tə bi ðæt. læn ɔfɝɾ ə hænd, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən si ɪt.

Nynaeve sat down hard on the ground; her legs would not hold her up. She remembered, but she shook her head anyway. It had to be coincidence. Or else Moiraine had asked more questions in Emond's Field than she had thought. The Aes Sedai had asked a great many questions. It had to be that. Lan offered a hand, but she did not even see it.

"aɪ wɪl ɡoʊ fɝðɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd wən nɪneɪiv kɛp saɪlənt. "ju juz ðə paʊɝ tə hil iðɝ pɛɹɪn əɹ ɛɡwin ət səm taɪm. ən əfɪnəɾi dɪvɛləps. jə kən sɛns ðə pɹɛzəns ə sʌmwʌn juv hild. ɪn bɛɹlən jə keɪm stʃɹeɪt tə ðə stæɡ ən laɪən, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə nɪɹəst ɪn tə ɛni ɡeɪt baɪ wɪtʃ jə kəɾ əv ɛntɝd. ʌv ðə pipəl fɹəm ɛmənz fild, oʊnli pɛɹɪn ən ɛɡwin wɝ ət ði ɪn wən jə ɝaɪvd. wɑz ɪt pɛɹɪn, əɹ ɛɡwin? əɹ boʊθ?"

"I will go further," Moiraine said when Nynaeve kept silent. "You used the Power to Heal either Perrin or Egwene at some time. An affinity develops. You can sense the presence of someone you have Healed. In Baerlon you came straight to the Stag and Lion, though it was not the nearest inn to any gate by which you could have entered. Of the people from Emond's Field, only Perrin and Egwene were at the inn when you arrived. Was it Perrin, or Egwene? Or both?"

"ɛɡwin," nɪneɪiv mʌmbəld. ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz teɪkən ɪt fəɹ ɡɹæntəd ðət ʃi kəd səmtaɪmz tɛl u wɑz əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ əɹ ivən wən ʃi kəd nɑt si ðɛm; nɑɾ əntɪl naʊ hæd ʃi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz sʌmwʌn ɑn hum əɹ kjʊɹz hæd wɝkt ɔlmoʊs mɝækjələsli wɛl. ən ʃi hæɾ ɔlweɪz noʊn wən ðə mɛɾəsən wəd wɝk bɪɑn ɛkspɛkteɪʃənz, ɔlweɪz fɛl ðə sɝɾənti wən ʃi sɛd ðə kɹɑps wəd bi ɪspɛʃli ɡʊd, əɹ ðət ðə ɹeɪnz wəd kʌm ɝli əɹ leɪt. ðət wɑz ðə weɪ ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz səpoʊz tə bi. nɑɾ ɔl wɪsdəmz kəd lɪsən tə ðə wɪnd, bʌt ðə bɛs kʊd. ðət wɑz wʌt mɪstʃɹəs bæɹən ɔlweɪz sɛd, dʒʌst əz ʃi sɛd nɪneɪiv wəd bi wʌn ə ðə bɛst.

"Egwene," Nynaeve mumbled. She had always taken it for granted that she could sometimes tell who was approaching her even when she could not see them; not until now had she realized that it was always someone on whom her cures had worked almost miraculously well. And she had always known when the medicine would work beyond expectations, always felt the certainty when she said the crops would be especially good, or that the rains would come early or late. That was the way she thought it was supposed to be. Not all Wisdoms could listen to the wind, but the best could. That was what Mistress Barran always said, just as she said Nynaeve would be one of the best.

"ʃi hæd bɹeɪkboʊn fivɝ." ʃi kɛpt əɹ hɛd daʊn ən spoʊk tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "aɪ wɑz stɪl əpɹɛntəs tə mɪstʃɹəs bæɹən, ən ʃi sɛt mi tə wɑtʃ ɛɡwin. aɪ wɑz jʌŋ, ən aɪ dɪdnt noʊ ðə wɪzdəm hæɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɛl ɪn hænd. ɪts tɛɹəbəl tə wɑtʃ, bɹeɪkboʊn fivɝ. ðə tʃaɪld wɑz soʊkt wɪð swɛt, ɡɹoʊnɪŋ ən twɪstɪŋ əntɪl aɪ kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ aɪ dɪdn hɪɹ əɹ boʊnz snæpɪŋ. mɪstʃɹəs bæɹən hæd toʊl mi ðə fivɝ wəd bɹeɪk ɪn ənʌðɝ deɪ, tu ət ðə moʊst, bʌɾ aɪ θɔt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ mi ə kaɪndnəs. aɪ θɔɾ ɛɡwin wɑz daɪɪŋ. aɪ juz tə lʊk æftɝ əɹ səmtaɪmz wən ʃi wɑz ə tɑdlɝ - wən əɹ mʌðɝ wɑz bɪzi - ən aɪ stɑɹɾəd kɹaɪɪŋ kəz aɪ wɑz gɑnə hæv tə wɑtʃ əɹ daɪ. wən mɪstʃɹəs bæɹən keɪm bæk ən aʊɝ leɪɾɝ, ðə fivɝ hæd bɹoʊkən. ʃi wɑz sɝpɹaɪzd, bʌt ʃi meɪɾ oʊvɝ mi mɔɹ ðən ɛɡwin. aɪ ɔlweɪz θɔt ʃi bɪlivd aɪ hæd ɡɪvən ðə tʃaɪl sʌmθɪŋ ən wɑz tu fɹaɪɾənd tə ədmɪɾ ɪt. aɪ ɔlweɪz θɔt ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kʌmfɝt mi, tə meɪk ʃʊɹ aɪ nu aɪ hædn hɝɾ ɛɡwin. ə wik leɪɾɝ aɪ fɛl ɑn ðə flɔɹ ɪn əɹ sɪɾɪŋ ɹum, ʃeɪkɪŋ ən bɝnɪŋ ʌp baɪ tɝnz. ʃi bʌndəl mi ɪndə bɛd, bʌt baɪ sʌpɝtaɪm ɪt wɑz ɡɔn."

"She had breakbone fever." She kept her head down and spoke to the ground. "I was still apprentice to Mistress Barran, and she set me to watch Egwene. I was young, and I didn't know the Wisdom had everything well in hand. It's terrible to watch, breakbone fever. The child was soaked with sweat, groaning and twisting until I could not understand why I didn't hear her bones snapping. Mistress Barran had told me the fever would break in another day, two at the most, but I thought she was doing me a kindness. I thought Egwene was dying. I used to look after her sometimes when she was a toddler - when her mother was busy - and I started crying because I was going to have to watch her die. When Mistress Barran came back an hour later, the fever had broken. She was surprised, but she made over me more than Egwene. I always thought she believed I had given the child something and was too frightened to admit it. I always thought she was trying to comfort me, to make sure I knew I hadn't hurt Egwene. A week later I fell on the floor in her sitting room, shaking and burning up by turns. She bundled me into bed, but by suppertime it was gone."

ʃi dʒɹɑpt əɹ hɛɾ ɪn əɹ hænz əz ʃi fɪnɪʃt spikɪŋ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tʃoʊz ə ɡʊɾ ɪɡzæmpəl, ʃi θɔt, laɪt bɝn hɝ! juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ laɪk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ə fɪlθi, dɑɹkfɹɛn ɛɛs sədaɪ!

She dropped her head in her hands as she finished speaking. The Aes Sedai chose a good example, she thought, Light burn her! Using the Power like an Aes Sedai. A filthy, Darkfriend Aes Sedai!

"ju wɝ vɛɹi lʌki," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, ən nɪneɪiv sæɾ ɪɹɛkt. læn stɛp bæk əz ɪf wʌt ðeɪ tɔkt əbaʊt wɑz nʌn ə hɪz bɪznəs, ən bɪzid hɪmsɛlf wɪð mændɑɹbz sæɾəl, nɑɾ ivən ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðɛm.

"You were very lucky," Moiraine said, and Nynaeve sat erect. Lan stepped back as if what they talked about was none of his business, and busied himself with Mandarb's saddle, not even glancing at them.

"lʌki!"

"Lucky!"

"ju hæv mænədʒd ə kɹud kəntʃɹoʊl oʊvɝ ðə paʊɝ, ivən ɪf tʌtʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs stɪl kʌmz ət ɹændəm. ɪf jə hæd nɑt, ɪt wʊɾə kɪl jə ɪvɛntʃəwəli. əz ɪt wɪl, ɪn ɔl pɹɑbəbɪləɾi, kɪl ɛɡwin ɪf jə mænədʒ tə stɑp əɹ fɹəm ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"You have managed a crude control over the Power, even if touching the True Source still comes at random. If you had not, it would have killed you eventually. As it will, in all probability, kill Egwene if you manage to stop her from going to Tar Valon."

"ɪf aɪ lɝn tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt. . . ." nɪneɪiv swɑloʊd hɑɹd. ɪt wɑz laɪk ædmɪɾɪŋ ɔl oʊvɝ əɡɛn ðət ʃi kəd də wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd. "ɪf aɪ lɝn tə kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt, soʊ kən ʃi. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid fəɹ əɹ tə ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ɡɛt mɪkst ʌp ɪn jəɹ ɪntʃɹiɡz."

"If I learned to control it. . . ." Nynaeve swallowed hard. It was like admitting all over again that she could do what the Aes Sedai said. "If I learned to control it, so can she. There is no need for her to go to Tar Valon, and get mixed up in your intrigues."

mɔɪɹeɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd sloʊli. "ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝtʃ fəɹ ɡɝlz u kən tʌtʃ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ənɡwaɪɾɪd dʒʌst əz əsɪdwəsli əz wi sɝtʃ fəɹ mɛn u kən də soʊ. ɪts nɑɾ ə dɪzaɪɝ tə ɪnkɹis əɹ nʌmbɝz - əɹ ət list, nɑɾ oʊnli ðət - nɔɹ ɪz ɪɾ ə fɪɹ ðət ðoʊz wɪmən wɪl mɪsjuz ðə paʊɝ. ðə ɹʌf kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə paʊɝ ðeɪ meɪ ɡeɪn, ɪf ðə laɪt ʃaɪnz ɑn ðɛm, ɪz ɹɛɹli ɪnʌf tə də ɛni ɡɹeɪt dæmədʒ, ɪspɛʃli sɪns ði æktʃəwəl tʌtʃɪŋ ə ðə sɔɹs ɪz bɪɑn ðɛɹ kəntʃɹoʊl wɪθaʊɾ ə titʃɝ, ən kʌmz oʊnli ɹændəmli. ænd, ʌv kɔɹs, ðeɪ də nɑt sʌfɝ ðə mædnəs ðət dʒɹaɪvz mɛn tə ivəl əɹ twɪstəd θɪŋz. wi wɑnə seɪv ðɛɹ lɪvz. ðə laɪvz ə ðoʊz u nɛvɝ də mænədʒ ɛni kəntʃɹoʊl əɾ ɔl."

Moiraine shook her head slowly. "Aes Sedai search for girls who can touch the True Source unguided just as assiduously as we search for men who can do so. It is not a desire to increase our numbers - or at least, not only that - nor is it a fear that those women will misuse the Power. The rough control of the Power they may gain, if the Light shines on them, is rarely enough to do any great damage, especially since the actual touching of the Source is beyond their control without a teacher, and comes only randomly. And, of course, they do not suffer the madness that drives men to evil or twisted things. We want to save their lives. The lives of those who never do manage any control at all."
