"ðə fivɝ ən tʃɪlz aɪ hæd kʊdn kɪl ɛniwʌn," nɪneɪiv ɪnsɪstəd. "nɑɾ ɪn θɹi əɹ fɔɹ aʊɝz. aɪ hæd ði ʌðɝ θɪŋz, tu, ən ðeɪ kʊdn kɪl ɛnibəɾi, iðɝ. ən ðeɪ stɑpt æftɝ ə fju mʌnθs. wʌɾ əbaʊt ðæt?"

"The fever and chills I had couldn't kill anyone," Nynaeve insisted. "Not in three or four hours. I had the other things, too, and they couldn't kill anybody, either. And they stopped after a few months. What about that?"

"ðoʊz wɝ oʊnli ɹiækʃənz," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd peɪʃənli. "itʃ taɪm, ðə ɹiækʃən kʌmz kloʊsɝ tə ði æktʃəwəl tʌtʃɪŋ ə ðə sɔɹs, əntɪl ðə tu hæpən ɔlmoʊs təɡɛðɝ. æftɝ ðət ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ mɔɹ ɹiækʃənz ðət kən bi sin, bʌɾ ɪts əz ɪf ə klɑk əz bɪɡʌn tɪkɪŋ. ə jɪɹ. tu jɪɹz. aɪ noʊ wʌn wʊmən u læstəd faɪv jɪɹz. ʌv fɔɹ u hæv ði ɪnbɔɹn əbɪləɾi ðət jə ən ɛɡwin hæv, θɹi daɪ ɪf wi də nɑt faɪn əm ən tʃɹeɪn ðɛm. ɪts nɑɾ əz hɔɹəbəl ə dɛθ əz ðə mɛn daɪ, bʌt niðɝ ɪz ɪt pɹɪɾi, ɪf ɛni dɛθ kən bi kɔl soʊ. kənvʌlʃənz. skɹimɪŋ. ɪt teɪks deɪz, ən wʌns ɪt bɪɡɪnz ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ ðət kən bi dʌn tə stɑp ɪt, nɑt baɪ ɔl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn təɡɛðɝ."

"Those were only reactions," Moiraine said patiently. "Each time, the reaction comes closer to the actual touching of the Source, until the two happen almost together. After that there are no more reactions that can be seen, but it is as if a clock has begun ticking. A year. Two years. I know one woman who lasted five years. Of four who have the inborn ability that you and Egwene have, three die if we do not find them and train them. It is not as horrible a death as the men die, but neither is it pretty, if any death can be called so. Convulsions. Screaming. It takes days, and once it begins there is nothing that can be done to stop it, not by all the Aes Sedai in Tar Valon together."

"jɔɹ laɪɪŋ. ɔl ðoʊz kwɛstʃənz jə æskt ɪn ɛmənz fild. jə faʊn aʊɾ əbaʊɾ ɛɡwinz fivɝ bɹeɪkɪŋ, əbaʊt maɪ fivɝ ən tʃɪlz, ɔl ʌv ɪt. jə meɪɾ ɔl ə ðɪs ʌp."

"You're lying. All those questions you asked in Emond's Field. You found out about Egwene's fever breaking, about my fever and chills, all of it. You made all of this up."

"ju noʊ aɪ dɪd nɑt," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd dʒɛnli.

"You know I did not," Moiraine said gently.

ɹɪlʌktənli, mɔɹ ɹɪlʌktənli ðən ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ dʌn ɛniθɪŋ ɪn əɹ laɪf, nɪneɪiv nɑɾəd. ɪt hæd bɪn ə læst stʌbɝn ɛfɝt tə dɪnaɪ wʌt wɑz pleɪn, ən ðəɹ wɑz nɛvɝ ɛni ɡʊɾ ɪn ðæt, haʊɛvɝ ənplɛzən ɪt maɪt bi. mɪstʃɹəs bæɹənz fɝst əpɹɛntəs hæd daɪd ðə weɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd wən nɪneɪiv wɑz stɪl pleɪɪŋ wɪð dɑlz, ən ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə jʌŋ wʊmən ɪn dɛvən ɹaɪɾ oʊnli ə fju jɪɹz əɡoʊ. ʃi hæd bɪn ə wɪzdəmz əpɹɛntəs, tu, wʌn u kəd lɪsən tə ðə wɪnd.

Reluctantly, more reluctantly than she had ever done anything in her life, Nynaeve nodded. It had been a last stubborn effort to deny what was plain, and there was never any good in that, however unpleasant it might be. Mistress Barran's first apprentice had died the way the Aes Sedai said when Nynaeve was still playing with dolls, and there had been a young woman in Deven Ride only a few years ago. She had been a Wisdom's apprentice, too, one who could listen to the wind.

"ju hæv ɡɹeɪt pətɛnʃəl, aɪ θɪŋk," mɔɪɹeɪn kəntɪnjud. "wɪð tʃɹeɪnɪŋ jə maɪt bɪkʌm ivən mɔɹ paʊɝfəl ðən ɛɡwin, ən aɪ bɪliv ʃi kən bɪkʌm wʌn ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪv sin ɪn sɛntʃɝiz."

"You have great potential, I think," Moiraine continued. "With training you might become even more powerful than Egwene, and I believe she can become one of the most powerful Aes Sedai we have seen in centuries."

nɪneɪiv pʊʃt hɝsɛlf bæk fɹəm ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ʃi wəɾ əv fɹəm ə vaɪpɝ. "noʊ! əl əv nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð - " wɪð wʌt? maɪsɛlf? ʃi slʌmpt, ən əɹ vɔɪs bɪkeɪm hɛzɪɾənt. "aɪ wəɾ æsk jə nɑt tə tɛl ɛniwʌn əbaʊt ðɪs. pliz?" ðə wɝd nɪɹli stʌk ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt. ʃi wəd ɹæðɝ tʃɹɑləks hæɾ əpɪɹd ðən ʃi hæd bɪn fɔɹs tə seɪ pliz tə ðɪs wʊmən. bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn oʊnli nɑɾəd əsɛnt, ən səm ə hɝ spɪɹət ɹɪtɝnd. "nʌn ə ðɪs ɪkspleɪnz wʌt jə wɑnt wɪð ɹænd, ən mæt, ən pɛɹɪn."

Nynaeve pushed herself back from the Aes Sedai as she would have from a viper. "No! I'll have nothing to do with - " With what? Myself? She slumped, and her voice became hesitant. "I would ask you not to tell anyone about this. Please?" The word nearly stuck in her throat. She would rather Trollocs had appeared than she had been forced to say please to this woman. But Moiraine only nodded assent, and some of her spirit returned. "None of this explains what you want with Rand, and Mat, and Perrin."

"ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑns ðɛm," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "ɪf ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑns ə θɪŋ, aɪ əpoʊz ɪt. kən ðəɹ bi ə sɪmpəlɝ ɹizən, əɹ ə bɛɾɝ?" ʃi fɪnɪʃt əɹ ti, wɑtʃɪŋ nɪneɪiv oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪm ə hɝ kʌp. "læn, wi mʌs bi ɡoʊɪŋ. saʊθ, aɪ θɪŋk. aɪ fɪɹ ðə wɪzdəm wɪl nɑt bi əkʌmpəniɪŋ ʌs."

"The Dark One wants them," Moiraine replied. "If the Dark One wants a thing, I oppose it. Can there be a simpler reason, or a better?" She finished her tea, watching Nynaeve over the rim of her cup. "Lan, we must be going. South, I think. I fear the Wisdom will not be accompanying us."

nɪneɪivz maʊθ taɪɾənd ət ðə weɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd "wɪzdəm"; ɪt sim tə sədʒɛst ʃi wɑz tɝnɪŋ əɹ bæk ɑn ɡɹeɪt θɪŋz ɪn feɪvɝ ə sʌmθɪŋ pɛɾi. ʃi dʌznt wɑn mi əlɔŋ. ʃiz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊt maɪ bæk ʌp soʊ əl ɡoʊ bæk hoʊm ən liv əm əloʊn wɪð hɝ. "oʊ, jɛs, əl bi ɡoʊɪŋ wɪð ju. jə kænɑt kip mi fɹəm ɪt."

Nynaeve's mouth tightened at the way the Aes Sedai said "Wisdom"; it seemed to suggest she was turning her back on great things in favor of something petty. She doesn't want me along. She's trying to put my back up so I'll go back home and leave them alone with her. "Oh, yes, I will be going with you. You cannot keep me from it."

"noʊ wʌn wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə kip jə fɹəm ɪt," læn sɛɾ əz i ɹidʒɔɪn ðɛm. hi ɛmptid ðə ti kɛɾəl oʊvɝ ðə faɪɝ ən stɝd ði æʃəz wɪð ə stɪk. "ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn?" hi sɛd tə mɔɪɹeɪn.

"No one will try to keep you from it," Lan said as he rejoined them. He emptied the tea kettle over the fire and stirred the ashes with a stick. "A part of the Pattern?" he said to Moiraine.

"pɝhæps soʊ," ʃi ɹɪplaɪd θɔtfəli. "aɪ ʃʊɾə spoʊkən tə mɪn əɡɛn."

"Perhaps so," she replied thoughtfully. "I should have spoken to Min again."

"ju si, nɪneɪiv, jə ɑɹ wɛlkəm tə kʌm." ðəɹ wɑz ə hɛzəteɪʃən ɪn ðə weɪ læn sɛɾ əɹ neɪm, ə hɪn ʌv ən ənspoʊkən "sədaɪ" æftɝ ɪt.

"You see, Nynaeve, you are welcome to come." There was a hesitation in the way Lan said her name, a hint of an unspoken "Sedai" after it.

nɪneɪiv bɹɪsəld, teɪkɪŋ ɪt fəɹ mɑkɝi, ən bɹɪsəld, tu, ət ðə weɪ ðeɪ spoʊk ə θɪŋz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ - θɪŋz ʃi nu nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt - wɪθaʊt ðə kɝɾəsi ʌv ən ɛkspləneɪʃən, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt ɡɪv əm ðə sæɾəsfækʃən ʌv æskɪŋ.

Nynaeve bristled, taking it for mockery, and bristled, too, at the way they spoke of things in front of her - things she knew nothing about - without the courtesy of an explanation, but she would not give them the satisfaction of asking.

ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɛn ɑn pɹipɛɹɪŋ fəɹ dɪpɑɹtʃɝ, hɪz ɛkənɑmɪkəl moʊʃənz soʊ ʃʊɹ ən swɪf ðəɾ i wɑz kwɪkli dʌn, sæɾəlbæɡz, blæŋkəts, ən ɔl fæsən bɪhaɪn ðə sæɾəlz ə mændɑɹb ən ɑldib.

The Warder went on preparing for departure, his economical motions so sure and swift that he was quickly done, saddlebags, blankets, and all fastened behind the saddles of Mandarb and Aldieb.

"aɪ wɪl fɛtʃ jəɹ hɔɹs," hi toʊl nɪneɪiv əz i fɪnɪʃt wɪð ðə læst sæɾəl taɪ.

"I will fetch your horse," he told Nynaeve as he finished with the last saddle tie.

hi stɑɹɾəd ʌp ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk, ən ʃi əlaʊd hɝsɛlf ə smɔl smaɪl. æftɝ ðə weɪ ʃi hæd wɑtʃt ɪm ʌndɪskʌvɝd, hi wɑz gɑnə tʃɹaɪ tə faɪn əɹ hɔɹs əneɪɾɪd. hi wəd lɝn ðət ʃi lɛf lɪɾəl ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv tʃɹæks wən ʃi wɑz stɔkɪŋ. ɪt wəd bi ə plɛʒɝ wən i keɪm bæk ɛmpti-hændəd.

He started up the riverbank, and she allowed herself a small smile. After the way she had watched him undiscovered, he was going to try to find her horse unaided. He would learn that she left little in the way of tracks when she was stalking. It would be a pleasure when he came back empty-handed.

"waɪ saʊθ?" ʃi æsk mɔɪɹeɪn. "aɪ hɝd jə seɪ wʌn ə ðə bɔɪz ɪz əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ. ən haʊ dʒju noʊ?"

"Why south?" she asked Moiraine. "I heard you say one of the boys is across the river. And how do you know?"

"aɪ ɡeɪv itʃ ə ðə bɔɪz ə toʊkən. ɪt kɹieɪɾəd ə bɑn ə sɔɹts bɪtwin əm ən mi. soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ ɑɹ əlaɪv ən əv ðoʊz kɔɪnz ɪn ðɛɹ pəzɛʃən, əl bi eɪbəl tə faɪn ðɛm." nɪneɪivz aɪz tɝn ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæd ɡɔn, ən mɔɪɹeɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "nɑt laɪk ðæt. ɪɾ oʊnli əlaʊz mi tə dɪskʌvɝ ɪf ðeɪ stɪl lɪv, ən faɪn əm ʃəd wi bɪkʌm sɛpɝeɪɾəd. pɹuɾənt, dʒju nɑt θɪŋk, ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz?"

"I gave each of the boys a token. It created a bond of sorts between them and me. So long as they are alive and have those coins in their possession, I will be able to find them." Nynaeve's eyes turned in the direction the Warder had gone, and Moiraine shook her head. "Not like that. It only allows me to discover if they still live, and find them should we become separated. Prudent, do you not think, under the circumstances?"

"aɪ doʊn laɪk ɛniθɪŋ ðət kənɛks jə wɪð ɛniwʌn fɹəm ɛmənz fild," nɪneɪiv sɛd stʌbɝnli. "bʌɾ ɪf ɪɾəl hɛlp əs faɪn ðɛm. . . ."

"I don't like anything that connects you with anyone from Emond's Field," Nynaeve said stubbornly. "But if it will help us find them. . . ."

"ɪt wɪl. aɪ wəd ɡæðɝ ðə jʌŋ mæn əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ fɝst, ɪf aɪ kʊd." fəɹ ə moʊmən fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən tɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz vɔɪs. "hi ɪz oʊnli ə fju maɪlz fɹəm ʌs. bʌɾ aɪ kænɑɾ əfɔɹd tə teɪk ðə taɪm. hi ʃəd meɪk ɪz weɪ daʊn tə waɪtbɹɪdʒ seɪfli naʊ ðət ðə tʃɹɑləks əv ɡɔn. ðə tu hu wɛn daʊnɹɪvɝ meɪ nid mi mɔɹ. ðeɪv lɔs ðɛɹ kɔɪnz, ən mɹdʒɹɑl ɑɹ iðɝ pɝsuɪŋ əm əɹ ɛls tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪntɝsɛpt əs ɔl ət waɪtbɹɪdʒ." ʃi saɪd. "aɪ mʌs teɪk kɛɹ ə ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst nid fɝst."

"It will. I would gather the young man across the river first, if I could." For a moment frustration tinged the Aes Sedai's voice. "He is only a few miles from us. But I cannot afford to take the time. He should make his way down to Whitebridge safely now that the Trollocs have gone. The two who went downriver may need me more. They have lost their coins, and Myrddraal are either pursuing them or else trying to intercept us all at Whitebridge." She sighed. "I must take care of the greatest need first."

"ðə mɹdʒɹɑl kəɾ əv . . . cʊɾə kɪl ðɛm," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

"The Myrddraal could have . . . could have killed them," Nynaeve said.

mɔɪɹeɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd slaɪtli, dɪnaɪɪŋ ðə sədʒɛstʃən əz ɪf ɪt wɝ tu tʃɹɪviəl tə bi kənsɪɾɝd. nɪneɪivz maʊθ taɪɾənd. "wɛɹ ɪz ɛɡwin, ðɛn? jə hævən ivən mɛnʃən hɝ."

Moiraine shook her head slightly, denying the suggestion as if it were too trivial to be considered. Nynaeve's mouth tightened. "Where is Egwene, then? You haven't even mentioned her."

"aɪ də nɑt noʊ," mɔɪɹeɪn ədmɪɾəd, "bʌɾ aɪ hoʊp ðət ʃiz seɪf."

"I do not know," Moiraine admitted, "but I hope that she is safe."

"ju doʊnt noʊ? jə hoʊp? ɔl ðət tɔk əbaʊt seɪvɪŋ əɹ laɪf baɪ teɪkɪŋ əɹ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ʃi kəd bi dɛd fəɹ ɔl jə noʊ!"

"You don't know? You hope? All that talk about saving her life by taking her to Tar Valon, and she could be dead for all you know!"

"aɪ kəd lʊk fəɹ əɹ ən əlaʊ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl mɔɹ taɪm bɪfɔɹ aɪ ɝaɪv tə hɛlp ðə tu jʌŋ mɛn u wɛn saʊθ. ɪts əm ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑns, nɑt hɝ. ðeɪ wəd nɑt bɑðɝ wɪð ɛɡwin, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðɛɹ tʃɹu kwɔɹi ɹɪmeɪnz ənkɔt."

"I could look for her and allow the Myrddraal more time before I arrive to help the two young men who went south. It is them the Dark One wants, not her. They would not bother with Egwene, so long as their true quarry remains uncaught."

nɪneɪiv ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ əɹ oʊn ɪnkaʊntɝ, bʌt ʃi ɹəfjuz tə ədmɪt ðə sɛns ʌv wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "soʊ ðə bɛs juv tə ɔfɝ ɪz ðət ʃi meɪ bi əlaɪv, ɪf ʃi wɑz lʌki. əlaɪv, meɪbi əloʊn, fɹaɪɾənd, ivən hɝt, deɪz fɹəm ðə nɪɹəs vɪlədʒ əɹ hɛlp ɪksɛp fəɹ ʌs. ən jə ɪntɛn tə liv hɝ."

Nynaeve remembered her own encounter, but she refused to admit the sense of what Moiraine said. "So the best you have to offer is that she may be alive, if she was lucky. Alive, maybe alone, frightened, even hurt, days from the nearest village or help except for us. And you intend to leave her."

"ʃi meɪ dʒʌst əz izəli bi seɪf wɪð ðə bɔɪ əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ. əɹ ɑn əɹ weɪ tə waɪtbɹɪdʒ wɪð ði ʌðɝ tu. ɪn ɛni keɪs, ðəɹ ɑɹ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ tʃɹɑləks hɪɹ tə θɹɛɾən hɝ, ən ʃiz stʃɹɔŋ, ɪntɛlədʒənt, ən kwaɪt keɪpəbəl ə faɪndɪŋ əɹ weɪ tə waɪtbɹɪdʒ əloʊn, ɪf nid bi. wəd jə ɹæðɝ steɪ ɑn ðə tʃæns ðət ʃi meɪ nid hɛlp, əɹ dʒju wɑnə tʃɹaɪ tə hɛlp ðoʊz wi noʊ ɑɹ ɪn nid? wəd juv mi sɝtʃ fəɹ əɹ ən lɛt ðə bɔɪz - ən ðə mɹdʒɹɑl u ɑɹ ʃʊɹli pɝsuɪŋ əm - ɡoʊ? əz mʌtʃ əz aɪ hoʊp fəɹ ɛɡwinz seɪfti, nɪneɪiv, aɪ faɪɾ əɡɛns ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ən fəɹ naʊ ðət sɛts maɪ pæθ."

"She may just as easily be safe with the boy across the river. Or on her way to Whitebridge with the other two. In any case, there are no longer Trollocs here to threaten her, and she is strong, intelligent, and quite capable of finding her way to Whitebridge alone, if need be. Would you rather stay on the chance that she may need help, or do you want to try to help those we know are in need? Would you have me search for her and let the boys - and the Myrddraal who are surely pursuing them - go? As much as I hope for Egwene's safety, Nynaeve, I fight against the Dark One, and for now that sets my path."

mɔɪɹeɪnz kɑm nɛvɝ slɪpt waɪl ʃi leɪɾ aʊt ðə hɔɹəbəl ɔltɝnəɾɪvz; nɪneɪiv wɑntəd tə skɹim ət hɝ. blɪŋkɪŋ bæk tɪɹz, ʃi tɝn əɹ feɪs soʊ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd nɑt si. laɪt, ə wɪzdəm ɪz səpoʊz tə lʊk æftɝ ɔl ə hɝ pipəl. waɪ də aɪ hæv tə tʃuz laɪk ðɪs?

Moiraine's calm never slipped while she laid out the horrible alternatives; Nynaeve wanted to scream at her. Blinking back tears, she turned her face so the Aes Sedai could not see. Light, a Wisdom is supposed to look after all of her people. Why do I have to choose like this?

"hɪɹ ɪz læn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, ɹaɪzɪŋ ən sɛɾəlɪŋ əɹ kloʊk əbaʊɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz.

"Here is Lan," Moiraine said, rising and settling her cloak about her shoulders.

tə nɪneɪiv ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə taɪni bloʊ əz ðə wɔɹɾɝ lɛɾ əɹ hɔɹs aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz. stɪl, hɝ lɪps θɪnd wən i hændəɾ əɹ ðə ɹeɪnz. ɪt wʊɾə bɪn ə smɔl bus tə hɝ spɪɹəts ɪf ðəɹ hæd bɪn ivən ə tʃɹeɪs ʌv ɡloʊɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz feɪs ɪnstɛɾ ə ðəɾ ɪnsʌfɝəbəl stoʊni kɑm. hɪz aɪz waɪɾənd wən i sɔ hɝ feɪs, ən ʃi tɝn əɹ bæk ɑn ɪm tə waɪp tɪɹz fɹəm əɹ tʃiks. haʊ dɛɹ i mɑk maɪ kɹaɪɪŋ!

To Nynaeve it was only a tiny blow as the Warder led her horse out of the trees. Still, her lips thinned when he handed her the reins. It would have been a small boost to her spirits if there had been even a trace of gloating on his face instead of that insufferable stony calm. His eyes widened when he saw her face, and she turned her back on him to wipe tears from her cheeks. How dare he mock my crying!

"ɑɹ jə kʌmɪŋ, wɪzdəm?" mɔɪɹeɪn æskt kuli.

"Are you coming, Wisdom?" Moiraine asked coolly.

ʃi tʊk wʌn læst, sloʊ lʊk ət ðə fɔɹəst, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ɛɡwin wɑz aʊt ðɛɹ, bɪfɔɹ sædli maʊntɪŋ əɹ hɔɹs. læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, tɝnɪŋ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz saʊθ. ʃi fɑloʊd, stɪf-bækt, ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə lɛt hɝsɛlf lʊk bæk; ɪnstɛd ʃi kɛpt əɹ aɪz ɑn mɔɪɹeɪn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz soʊ kɑnfəɾənt ɪn əɹ paʊɝ ən əɹ plænz, ʃi θɔt, bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ dɪd nɑt faɪn ɛɡwin ən ðə bɔɪz, ɔl ə ðɛm, əlaɪv ən ənhɑɹmd, nɑɾ ɔl ə hɝ paʊɝ wəd pɹətɛk hɝ. nɑɾ ɔl əɹ paʊɝ. aɪ kən juz ɪt, wʊmən! jə toʊl mi soʊ jɝsɛlf. aɪ kən juz ɪɾ əɡɛns ju!

She took one last, slow look at the forest, wondering if Egwene was out there, before sadly mounting her horse. Lan and Moiraine were already in their saddles, turning their horses south. She followed, stiff-backed, refusing to let herself look back; instead she kept her eyes on Moiraine. The Aes Sedai was so confident in her power and her plans, she thought, but if they did not find Egwene and the boys, all of them, alive and unharmed, not all of her power would protect her. Not all her Power. I can use it, woman! You told me so yourself. I can use it against you!


tʃæptɝ twɛntiɾu


CHAPTER 22

eɪ pæθ tʃoʊzən


A Path Chosen

ɪn ə smɔl kɑps ə tʃɹiz, bɪniθ ə paɪl ə siɾɝ bɹæntʃəz ɹʌfli kʌɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk, pɛɹɪn slɛp lɔŋ æftɝ sʌnɹaɪz. ɪt wɑz ðə siɾɝ niɾəlz, pɹɪkɪŋ ɪm θɹu hɪz stɪl-dæmp kloʊðz, ðət faɪnəli pɹɪk θɹu hɪz ɪɡzɔstʃən əz wɛl. dip ɪn ə dʒɹim ʌv ɛmənz fild, ʌv wɝkɪŋ ət mæstɝ luhənz fɔɹdʒ, hi oʊpən ɪz aɪz ən stɛɹd, ʌnkɑmpɹihɛndɪŋ, ət ðə swit-smɛlɪŋ bɹæntʃəz ɪntɝwoʊvən oʊvɝ ɪz feɪs, sʌnlaɪt tʃɹɪklɪŋ θɹu.

In a small copse of trees, beneath a pile of cedar branches roughly cut in the dark, Perrin slept long after sunrise. It was the cedar needles, pricking him through his still-damp clothes, that finally pricked through his exhaustion as well. Deep in a dream of Emond's Field, of working at Master Luhhan's forge, he opened his eyes and stared, uncomprehending, at the sweet-smelling branches interwoven over his face, sunlight trickling through.

moʊst ə ðə bɹæntʃəz fɛl əweɪ əz i sæɾ ʌp ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, bʌt səm hʌŋ hæfəzɝdli fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, ən ivən ɪz hɛd, meɪkɪŋ ɪm əpɪɹ sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ə tʃɹi hɪmsɛlf. ɛmənz fil feɪɾəd əz mɛmɹi ɹʌʃt bæk, soʊ vɪvəd ðət fəɹ ə moʊmən ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ simd mɔɹ ɹil ðən ɛniθɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪm naʊ.

Most of the branches fell away as he sat up in surprise, but some hung haphazardly from his shoulders, and even his head, making him appear something like a tree himself. Emond's Field faded as memory rushed back, so vivid that for a moment the night before seemed more real than anything around him now.

pæntɪŋ, fɹæntɪk, hi skɹæbəld ɪz æks aʊɾ ə ðə paɪl. hi klʌtʃt ɪɾ ɪn boʊθ hænz ən pɪɹɾ ɝaʊn kɔʃəsli, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz bɹɛθ. nʌθɪŋ muvd. ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɑz koʊld ən stɪl. ɪf ðəɹ wɝ tʃɹɑləks ɑn ði is bæŋk ə ði ɑɹɪnɛl, ðeɪ wɝ nɑt muvɪŋ, ət lis nɑt kloʊs tə hɪm. teɪkɪŋ ə dip, kɑmɪŋ bɹɛθ, hi loʊɝd ði æks tə hɪz niz, ən weɪɾəd ə moʊmən fəɹ ɪz hɑɹt tə stɑp paʊndɪŋ.

Panting, frantic, he scrabbled his axe out of the pile. He clutched it in both hands and peered around cautiously, holding his breath. Nothing moved. The morning was cold and still. If there were Trollocs on the east bank of the Arinelle, they were not moving, at least not close to him. Taking a deep, calming breath, he lowered the axe to his knees, and waited a moment for his heart to stop pounding.

ðə smɔl stæn ʌv ɛvɝɡɹinz sɝaʊndɪŋ ɪm wɑz ðə fɝst ʃɛltɝ i hæd faʊn læs naɪt. ɪt wɑz spɑɹs ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv lɪɾəl pɹətɛkʃən əɡɛnst wɑtʃɪŋ aɪz ɪf i stʊɾ ʌp. plʌkɪŋ bɹæntʃəz fɹəm ɪz hɛɾ ən ʃoʊldɝz, hi pʊʃt əsaɪd ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz pɹɪkli blæŋkət, ðən kɹɔld ɑn hænz ən niz tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə kɑps. ðəɹ i leɪ stʌɾiɪŋ ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk ən skɹætʃɪŋ wɛɹ ðə niɾəlz hæd stæb hɪm.

The small stand of evergreens surrounding him was the first shelter he had found last night. It was sparse enough to give little protection against watching eyes if he stood up. Plucking branches from his head and shoulders, he pushed aside the rest of his prickly blanket, then crawled on hands and knees to the edge of the copse. There he lay studying the riverbank and scratching where the needles had stabbed him.

ðə kʌɾɪŋ wɪn ə ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ hæd feɪɾəd tə ə saɪlən bɹiz ðət bɛɹli ɹɪpəl ðə sɝfəs ə ðə wɔɾɝ. ðə ɹɪvɝ ɹæn baɪ, kɑm ən ɛmpti. ən waɪd. ʃʊɹli tu waɪɾ ən tu dip fəɹ feɪdz tə kɹɔs. ðə fɑɹ bæŋk əpɪɹɾ ə sɑləd mæs ə tʃɹiz əz fɑɹ əz i kəd si ʌpɹɪvɝ ən daʊn. sɝɾənli nʌθɪŋ muvd ɪn ɪz vju oʊvɝ ðɛɹ.

The cutting wind of the night before had faded to a silent breeze that barely rippled the surface of the water. The river ran by, calm and empty. And wide. Surely too wide and too deep for Fades to cross. The far bank appeared a solid mass of trees as far as he could see upriver and down. Certainly nothing moved in his view over there.

hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ hi fɛlt əbaʊt ðæt. feɪdz ən tʃɹɑləks i kəd də wɪθaʊt kwaɪɾ izəli, ivən ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ, bʌɾ ə hoʊl lɪst ʌv wɝiz wʊɾə vænɪʃt wɪð ði əpɪɹəns ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, əɹ ðə wɔɹɾɝ, ɔɹ, ivən bɛɾɝ, ɛni ʌv ɪz fɹɛnz. ɪf wɪʃɪz wɝ wɪŋz, ʃip wəd flaɪ. ðət wɑz wʌt mɪstʃɹəs luhən ɔlweɪz sɛd.

He was not sure how he felt about that. Fades and Trollocs he could do without quite easily, even on the other side of the river, but a whole list of worries would have vanished with the appearance of the Aes Sedai, or the Warder, or, even better, any of his friends. If wishes were wings, sheep would fly. That was what Mistress Luhhan always said.

hi hæd nɑt sin ə saɪn ə hɪz hɔɹs sɪns ɹaɪɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə blʌf - hi hoʊpt ɪt hæd swʌm aʊɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ seɪfli - bʌɾ i wɑz mɔɹ juz tə wɔkɪŋ ðən ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɛniweɪ, ən ɪz buts wɝ staʊɾ ən wɛl soʊld. hi hæd nʌθɪŋ tə it, bʌɾ ɪz slɪŋ wɑz stɪl ɹæpt ɝaʊn ɪz weɪst, ən ðəɾ əɹ ðə snɑɹəlaɪnz ɪn ɪz pɑkəɾ ɔt tə jild ə ɹæbəɾ ɪn ə lɪɾəl taɪm. ɛvɹiθɪŋ fəɹ meɪkɪŋ ə faɪɝ wɑz ɡɔn wɪð ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz, bʌt ðə siɾɝ tʃɹiz wəd jil tɪndɝ ən ə faɪɝboʊ wɪð ə bɪɾ ʌv wɝk.

He had not seen a sign of his horse since riding over the bluff - he hoped it had swum out of the river safely - but he was more used to walking than riding anyway, and his boots were stout and well soled. He had nothing to eat, but his sling was still wrapped around his waist, and that or the snarelines in his pocket ought to yield a rabbit in a little time. Everything for making a fire was gone with his saddlebags, but the cedar trees would yield tinder and a firebow with a bit of work.

hi ʃɪvɝɾ əz ðə bɹiz ɡʌstɪɾ ɪndə hɪz haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs. hɪz kloʊk wɑz sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ, ən ɪz koʊɾ ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls i wɔɹ wɝ stɪl klæmi koʊl fɹəm ðə soʊkɪŋ ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ. hi hæd bɪn tu taɪɝd fəɹ ðə koʊld ən dæmp tə bɑðɝ ɪm læs naɪt, bʌt naʊ hi wɑz waɪɾ əweɪk tə ɛvɹi tʃɪl. dʒʌs ðə seɪm, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd əɡɛns hæŋɪŋ ɪz kloʊðz ɑn ðə bɹæntʃəz tə dʒɹaɪ. ɪf ðə deɪ wɑz nɑt pɹɪsaɪsli koʊld, ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ivən kloʊs tə wɔɹm.

He shivered as the breeze gusted into his hiding place. His cloak was somewhere in the river, and his coat and everything else he wore were still clammy cold from the soaking in the river. He had been too tired for the cold and damp to bother him last night, but now he was wide awake to every chill. Just the same, he decided against hanging his clothes on the branches to dry. If the day was not precisely cold, it was not even close to warm.

taɪm wɑz ðə pɹɑbləm, hi θɔt wɪð ə saɪ. dʒɹaɪ kloʊðz, wɪð ə lɪɾəl taɪm. ə ɹæbət tə ɹoʊst ən ə faɪɝ tə ɹoʊst ɪɾ oʊvɝ, wɪð ə lɪɾəl taɪm. hɪz stʌmək ɹʌmbəld, ən i tʃɹaɪd tə fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊɾ iɾɪŋ ɔltəɡɛðɝ. ðəɹ wɝ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt jusəz fəɹ ðət taɪm. wʌn θɪŋ əɾ ə taɪm, ən ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt fɝst. ðət wɑz ɪz weɪ.

Time was the problem, he thought with a sigh. Dry clothes, with a little time. A rabbit to roast and a fire to roast it over, with a little time. His stomach rumbled, and he tried to forget about eating altogether. There were more important uses for that time. One thing at a time, and the most important first. That was his way.

hɪz aɪz fɑloʊd ðə stʃɹɔŋ floʊ ʌv ði ɑɹɪnɛl daʊnɹɪvɝ. hi wɑz ə stʃɹɔŋɝ swɪmɝ ðən ɛɡwin. ɪf ʃi hæd meɪɾ ɪɾ əkɹɔs. . . . noʊ, nɑɾ ɪf. ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ʃi hæd meɪɾ ɪɾ əkɹɔs wəd bi daʊnɹɪvɝ. hi dʒɹʌmd ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, weɪɪŋ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ.

His eyes followed the strong flow of the Arinelle downriver. He was a stronger swimmer than Egwene. If she had made it across. . . . No, not if. The place where she had made it across would be downriver. He drummed on the ground with his fingers, weighing, considering.

hɪz dɪsɪʒən meɪd, hi weɪstəd noʊ taɪm ɪn pɪkɪŋ ʌp ɪz æks ən sɛɾɪŋ ɔf daʊn ðə ɹɪvɝ.

His decision made, he wasted no time in picking up his axe and setting off down the river.

ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði ɑɹɪnɛl læk ðə θɪk fɔɹəst ə ðə wɛs bæŋk. klʌmps ə tʃɹiz spɑɾəd əkɹɔs wʌt wəd bi ɡɹæslæn ɪf spɹɪŋ ɛvɝ keɪm. səm wɝ bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə bi kɔl θɪkəts, wɪð swɑðz ʌv ɛvɝɡɹinz əmʌŋ ðə bæɹən æʃ ən ɔldɝ ən hɑɹdɡəm. daʊn baɪ ðə ɹɪvɝ ðə stænz wɝ smɔlɝ ən nɑt soʊ taɪt. ðeɪ ɡeɪv pʊɹ kʌvɝ, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ðə kʌvɝ ðəɹ wɑz.

This side of the Arinelle lacked the thick forest of the west bank. Clumps of trees spotted across what would be grassland if spring ever came. Some were big enough to be called thickets, with swathes of evergreens among the barren ash and alder and hardgum. Down by the river the stands were smaller and not so tight. They gave poor cover, but they were all the cover there was.

hi dæʃt fɹəm ɡɹoʊθ tə ɡɹoʊθ ɪn ə kɹaʊtʃ, θɹoʊɪŋ hɪmsɛlf daʊn wən i wɑz əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz tə stʌɾi ðə ɹɪvɝbɑŋks, ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ əz wɛl əz hɪz. ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd ðə ɹɪvɝ wəd bi ə bæɹiɝ tə feɪdz ən tʃɹɑləks, bʌt wəɾ ɪt? siɪŋ ɪm maɪt bi ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝkʌm ðɛɹ ɹɪlʌktəns tə kɹɔs dip wɔɾɝ. soʊ hi wɑtʃt kɛɹfəli fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə tʃɹiz ən ɹæn fɹəm wʌn haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs tə ðə nɛkst, fæst ən loʊ.

He dashed from growth to growth in a crouch, throwing himself down when he was among the trees to study the riverbanks, the far side as well as his. The Warder said the river would be a barrier to Fades and Trollocs, but would it? Seeing him might be enough to overcome their reluctance to cross deep water. So he watched carefully from behind the trees and ran from one hiding place to the next, fast and low.

hi kʌvɝd sɛvɹəl maɪlz ðət weɪ, ɪn spɝts, əntɪl sʌɾənli, hæfweɪ tə ðə bɛkənɪŋ ʃɛltɝ ʌv ə ɡɹoʊθ ʌv wɪloʊz, hi ɡɹʌntɪɾ ən stɑp dɛd, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ɡɹaʊnd. pætʃəz ə bɛɹ ɝθ spɑɾəd ðə mæɾɪd bɹaʊn ə læs jɪɹz ɡɹæs, ən ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv wʌn ə ðoʊz pætʃəz, ɹaɪɾ ʌndɝ ɪz noʊz, wɑz ə klɪɹ hʊfpɹɪnt. ə sloʊ smaɪl spɹɛɾ əkɹɔs ɪz feɪs. səm tʃɹɑləks hæd hʊvz, bʌɾ i daʊɾɪd ɪf ɛni wɔɹ hɔɹsʃuz, ɪspɛʃli hɔɹsʃuz wɪð ðə dʌbəl kɹɔsbɝ mæstɝ luhən æɾəd fəɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ.

He covered several miles that way, in spurts, until suddenly, halfway to the beckoning shelter of a growth of willows, he grunted and stopped dead, staring at the ground. Patches of bare earth spotted the matted brown of last year's grass, and in the middle of one of those patches, right under his nose, was a clear hoofprint. A slow smile spread across his face. Some Trollocs had hooves, but he doubted if any wore horseshoes, especially horseshoes with the double crossbar Master Luhhan added for strength.

fɝɡɛɾɪŋ pɑsəbəl aɪz ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹɪvɝ, hi kæst əbaʊt fəɹ mɔɹ tʃɹæks. ðə pleɪɾəd kɑɹpəɾ ə dɛd ɡɹæs dɪd nɑt teɪk ɪmpɹɛʃənz wɛl, bʌɾ ɪz ʃɑɹp aɪz faʊn əm ɛniweɪ. ðə skænti tʃɹeɪl lɛɾ ɪm stʃɹeɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ tə ə dɛns stæn ə tʃɹiz, θɪk wɪð lɛðɝlif ən siɾɝ ðət meɪɾ ə wɔl əɡɛnst wɪn əɹ pɹaɪɪŋ aɪz. ðə spɹɛɾɪŋ bɹæntʃəz ʌv ə loʊn hɛmlɑk taʊɝɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪɾ ɔl.

Forgetting possible eyes on the other side of the river, he cast about for more tracks. The plaited carpet of dead grass did not take impressions well, but his sharp eyes found them anyway. The scanty trail led him straight away from the river to a dense stand of trees, thick with leatherleaf and cedar that made a wall against wind or prying eyes. The spreading branches of a lone hemlock towered in the middle of it all.

stɪl ɡɹɪnɪŋ, hi pʊʃt ɪz weɪ θɹu ði ɪntɝwoʊvən bɹæntʃəz, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ haʊ mʌtʃ nɔɪz i meɪd. əbɹʌpli hi stɛpt ɪndə ə lɪɾəl klɪɹɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə hɛmlɑk - ən stɑpt. bɪhaɪn ə smɔl faɪɝ, ɛɡwin kɹaʊtʃt, hɝ feɪs ɡɹɪm, wɪð ə θɪk bɹæntʃ hɛld laɪk ə klʌb ən əɹ bæk əɡɛns bɛləz flæŋk.

Still grinning, he pushed his way through the interwoven branches, not caring how much noise he made. Abruptly he stepped into a little clearing under the hemlock - and stopped. Behind a small fire, Egwene crouched, her face grim, with a thick branch held like a club and her back against Bela's flank.

"aɪ ɡɛs aɪ ʃʊɾə kɔld aʊt," hi sɛd wɪð ən əbæʃt ʃɹʌɡ.

"I guess I should have called out," he said with an abashed shrug.

tɔsɪŋ əɹ klʌb daʊn, ʃi ɹæn tə θɹoʊ hɝ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɪm. "aɪ θɔt jə hæd dʒɹaʊnd. jəɹ stɪl wɛt. hɪɹ, sɪt baɪ ðə faɪɝ ən wɔɹm jɝsɛlf. jə lɔs jəɹ hɔɹs, dɪdn ju?"

Tossing her club down, she ran to throw her arms around him. "I thought you had drowned. You're still wet. Here, sit by the fire and warm yourself. You lost your horse, didn't you?"

hi lɛɾ əɹ pʊʃ ɪm tə ə pleɪs baɪ ðə faɪɝ ən ɹʌbd ɪz hænz oʊvɝ ðə fleɪmz, ɡɹeɪtfəl fəɹ ðə wɔɹmθ. ʃi pɹədust ən ɔɪl peɪpɝ pækət fɹəm əɹ sæɾəlbæɡz ən ɡeɪv ɪm səm bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz. ðə pækədʒ hæd bɪn soʊ taɪtli ɹæp ðəɾ ivən æftɝ ɪts dʌŋkɪŋ ðə fud wɑz dʒɹaɪ. hɪɹ jə wɝ wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt hɝ, ən ʃiz dʌn bɛɾɝ ðən jə dɪd.

He let her push him to a place by the fire and rubbed his hands over the flames, grateful for the warmth. She produced an oiled paper packet from her saddlebags and gave him some bread and cheese. The package had been so tightly wrapped that even after its dunking the food was dry. Here you were worrying about her, and she's done better than you did.

"bɛlə ɡɑt mi əkɹɔs," ɛɡwin sɛd, pæɾɪŋ ðə ʃæɡi mɛɹ. "ʃi hɛɾəd əweɪ fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑləks ən dʒʌs toʊd mi əlɔŋ." ʃi pɔzd. "aɪ hævən sin ɛnibəɾi ɛls, pɛɹɪn."

"Bela got me across," Egwene said, patting the shaggy mare. "She headed away from the Trollocs and just towed me along." She paused. "I haven't seen anybody else, Perrin."

hi hɝd ði ənspoʊkən kwɛstʃən. ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli aɪɪŋ ðə pækət ðət ʃi wɑz ɹiɹæpɪŋ, hi lɪk ðə læs kɹʌmz fɹəm ɪz fɪŋɡɝz bɪfɔɹ spikɪŋ. "aɪv sin noʊ wʌn bʌt jə sɪns læs naɪt. noʊ feɪdz əɹ tʃɹɑləks, iðɝ; ðɛɹz ðæt."

He heard the unspoken question. Regretfully eyeing the packet that she was rewrapping, he licked the last crumbs from his fingers before speaking. "I've seen no one but you since last night. No Fades or Trollocs, either; there's that."

"ɹæn əz tə bi ɔl ɹaɪt," ɛɡwin sɛd, kwɪkli æɾɪŋ, "ðeɪ ɔl du. ðeɪv tə. ðəɹ pɹɑbli lʊkɪŋ fəɹ əs ɹaɪt naʊ. ðeɪ maɪt faɪn əs ɛnitaɪm naʊ. mɔɪɹeɪn ɪz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, æftɝ ɔl."

"Rand has to be all right," Egwene said, quickly adding, "they all do. They have to. They're probably looking for us right now. They might find us anytime now. Moiraine is an Aes Sedai, after all."

"aɪ kip biɪŋ ɹimaɪndəɾ ə ðæt," hi sɛd. "bɝn mi, aɪ wɪʃ aɪ kəd fɝɡɛt."

"I keep being reminded of that," he said. "Burn me, I wish I could forget."

"aɪ dɪd nɑt hɪɹ jə kəmpleɪnɪŋ wən ʃi stɑp ðə tʃɹɑləks fɹəm kætʃɪŋ ʌs," ɛɡwin sɛd tɑɹtli.

"I did not hear you complaining when she stopped the Trollocs from catching us," Egwene said tartly.

"aɪ dʒʌst wɪʃ wi kəd də wɪθaʊt hɝ." hi ʃɹʌɡd ənkʌmftəbli ʌndɝ əɹ stɛɾi ɡeɪz. "aɪ səpoʊz wi kænt, ðoʊ. aɪv bɪn θɪŋkɪŋ." hɝ aɪbɹaʊz ɹoʊz, bʌɾ i wɑz juz tə sɝpɹaɪz wɛnɛvɝ i kleɪmd ən aɪdiə. ivən wən ɪz aɪdiəz wɝ əz ɡʊɾ əz ðɛɹz, ðeɪ ɔlweɪz ɹɪmɛmbɝd haʊ dɪlɪbɝɪɾ i wɑz ɪn θɪŋkɪŋ ə ðɛm. "wi kən weɪt fəɹ læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn tə faɪn ʌs."

"I just wish we could do without her." He shrugged uncomfortably under her steady gaze. "I suppose we can't, though. I've been thinking." Her eyebrows rose, but he was used to surprise whenever he claimed an idea. Even when his ideas were as good as theirs, they always remembered how deliberate he was in thinking of them. "We can wait for Lan and Moiraine to find us."

"ʌv kɔɹs," ʃi kʌɾ ɪn. "mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛd ʃi wəd faɪn əs ɪf wi wɝ sɛpɝeɪɾəd."

"Of course," she cut in. "Moiraine Sedai said she would find us if we were separated."

hi lɛɾ əɹ fɪnɪʃ, ðən wɛn ɑn. "ɔɹ ðə tʃɹɑləks kəd faɪn ʌs, fɝst. mɔɪɹeɪn kəd bi dɛd, tu. ɔl ə ðɛm kəd bi. noʊ, ɛɡwin. aɪm sɑɹi, bʌt ðeɪ kəd bi. aɪ hoʊp ðeɪ ɑɹ ɔl seɪf. aɪ hoʊp ðəl wɔk ʌp tə ðɪs faɪɝ ɛni mɪnət. bʌt hoʊp ɪz laɪk ə pis ə stʃɹɪŋ wən jəɹ dʒɹaʊnɪŋ; ɪt dʒʌst ɪzən ɪnʌf tə ɡɛt jə aʊt baɪ ɪtsɛlf."

He let her finish, then went on. "Or the Trollocs could find us, first. Moiraine could be dead, too. All of them could be. No, Egwene. I'm sorry, but they could be. I hope they are all safe. I hope they'll walk up to this fire any minute. But hope is like a piece of string when you're drowning; it just isn't enough to get you out by itself."

ɛɡwin kloʊzd əɹ maʊθ ən stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm wɪð əɹ dʒɔ sɛt. faɪnəli, ʃi sɛd, "ju wɑnə ɡoʊ daʊnɹɪvɝ tə waɪtbɹɪdʒ? ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ dʌzn faɪn əs hɪɹ, ðæts wɛɹ ʃɪl lʊk nɛkst."

Egwene closed her mouth and stared at him with her jaw set. Finally, she said, "You want to go downriver to Whitebridge? If Moiraine Sedai doesn't find us here, that's where she will look next."

"aɪ səpoʊz," hi sɛd sloʊli, "ðæt waɪtbɹɪdʒ ɪz wɛɹ wi ʃəd ɡoʊ. bʌt ðə feɪdz pɹɑbli noʊ ðæt, tu. ðæts wɛɹ ðəl bi lʊkɪŋ, ən ðɪs taɪm wi doʊn əv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ ə wɔɹɾɝ tə pɹətɛkt ʌs."

"I suppose," he said slowly, "that Whitebridge is where we should go. But the Fades probably know that, too. That's where they'll be looking, and this time we don't have an Aes Sedai or a Warder to protect us."

"aɪ səpoʊz jəɹ gɑnə sədʒɛst ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf sʌmwɛɹ, ðə weɪ mæt wɑntəd tə? haɪɾɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ ðə feɪdz ən tʃɹɑləks woʊn faɪn ʌs? əɹ mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ, iðɝ?"

"I suppose you're going to suggest running off somewhere, the way Mat wanted to? Hiding somewhere the Fades and Trollocs won't find us? Or Moiraine Sedai, either?"

"doʊn θɪŋk aɪ hævən kənsɪɾɝd ɪt," hi sɛd kwaɪətli. "bʌɾ ɛvɹi taɪm wi θɪŋk wəɹ fɹi, feɪdz ən tʃɹɑləks faɪn əs əɡɛn. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf ðəɹ ɪz ɛnipleɪs wi kəd haɪd fɹəm ðɛm. aɪ doʊn laɪk ɪt mʌtʃ, bʌt wi nid mɔɪɹeɪn."

"Don't think I haven't considered it," he said quietly. "But every time we think we are free, Fades and Trollocs find us again. I don't know if there is anyplace we could hide from them. I don't like it much, but we need Moiraine."

"aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn ðɛn, pɛɹɪn. wɛɹ də wi ɡoʊ?"

"I don't understand then, Perrin. Where do we go?"

hi blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. ʃi wɑz weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪz ænsɝ. weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə tɛl əɹ wʌt tə du. ɪt hæd nɛvɝ əkɝd tə hɪm ðət ʃi wəd lʊk tə hɪm tə teɪk ðə lɛd. ɛɡwin nɛvɝ laɪk duɪŋ wʌt sʌmwʌn ɛls hæd plæn aʊt, ən ʃi nɛvɝ lɛɾ ɛnibəɾi tɛl əɹ wʌt tə du. ɪksɛp meɪbi ðə wɪzdəm, ən i θɔt səmtaɪmz ʃi bɔkt ət ðæt. hi smuðd ðə dɝɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm wɪð ɪz hæn ən klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt ɹʌfli.

He blinked in surprise. She was waiting for his answer. Waiting for him to tell her what to do. It had never occurred to him that she would look to him to take the lead. Egwene never liked doing what someone else had planned out, and she never let anybody tell her what to do. Except maybe the Wisdom, and he thought sometimes she balked at that. He smoothed the dirt in front of him with his hand and cleared his throat roughly.

"ɪf ðɪs ɪz wɛɹ wəɹ naʊ, ən ðəɾ ɪz waɪtbɹɪdʒ," hi stæb ðə ɡɹaʊn twaɪs wɪð ɪz fɪŋɡɝ, "ðɛn keɪɛmlɪn ʃəd bi sʌmwɛɹ ɝaʊn hɪɹ." hi meɪɾ ə θɝd mɑɹk, ɔf tə ðə saɪd.

"If this is where we are now, and that is Whitebridge," he stabbed the ground twice with his finger, "then Caemlyn should be somewhere around here." He made a third mark, off to the side.

hi pɔzd, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə θɹi dɑts ɪn ðə dɝt. hɪz ɪntaɪɝ plæn wɑz beɪst ɑn wʌɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ə hɝ fɑðɝz oʊl mæp. mæstɝ ælvɪɹ sɛɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt tu ækjɝət, ænd, ɛniweɪ, hi hæd nɛvɝ mun oʊvɝ ɪɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ɹænd ən mæt. bʌɾ ɛɡwin sɛd nʌθɪŋ. wən i lʊkt ʌp, ʃi wɑz stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm wɪð əɹ hænz ɪn əɹ læp.

He paused, looking at the three dots in the dirt. His entire plan was based on what he remembered of her father's old map. Master al'Vere said it was not too accurate, and, anyway, he had never mooned over it as much as Rand and Mat. But Egwene said nothing. When he looked up, she was still watching him with her hands in her lap.

"keɪɛmlɪn?" ʃi saʊndəd stʌnd.

"Caemlyn?" She sounded stunned.

"keɪɛmlɪn." hi dʒɹu ə laɪn ɪn ðə dɝt bɪtwin tu ʌv ðə dɑts. "əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ, ən stʃɹeɪɾ əkɹɔs. noʊbɑdi wəɾ ɪkspɛk ðæt. wɪl weɪt fəɹ əm ɪn keɪɛmlɪn." hi dʌstɪɾ ɪz hænz ən weɪɾəd. hi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd plæn, bʌt ʃʊɹli ʃi wəɾ əv əbdʒɛkʃənz naʊ. hi ɪkspɛktəd ʃi wəd teɪk tʃɑɹdʒ - ʃi wɑz ɔlweɪz bʊliɪŋ ɪm ɪndə sʌmθɪŋ - ən ðət wɑz ɔl ɹaɪt wɪð hɪm.

"Caemlyn." He drew a line in the dirt between two of the dots. "Away from the river, and straight across. Nobody would expect that. We'll wait for them in Caemlyn." He dusted his hands and waited. He thought it was a good plan, but surely she would have objections now. He expected she would take charge - she was always bullying him into something - and that was all right with him.

tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ʃi nɑɾəd. "ðɛɹ mʌs bi vɪlədʒəz. wi kən æsk dɝɛkʃənz."

To his surprise, she nodded. "There must be villages. We can ask directions."

"wʌt wɝiz mi," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "ɪz wʌt wi də ɪf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dʌzn faɪn əs ðɛɹ. laɪt, huɾ ɛvɝ əv θɔɾ aɪd wɝi əbaʊt sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðæt? wʌɾ ɪf ʃi dʌzn kʌm tə keɪɛmlɪn? meɪbi ʃi θɪŋks wɝ dɛd. meɪbi ʃɪl teɪk ɹænd ən mæt stʃɹeɪt tə tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"What worries me," Perrin said, "is what we do if the Aes Sedai doesn't find us there. Light, who'd ever have thought I'd worry about something like that? What if she doesn't come to Caemlyn? Maybe she thinks we're dead. Maybe she'll take Rand and Mat straight to Tar Valon."

"mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛd ʃi kəd faɪn ʌs," ɛɡwin sɛd fɝmli. "ɪf ʃi kən faɪn əs hɪɹ, ʃi kən faɪn əs ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ən ʃi wɪl."

"Moiraine Sedai said she could find us," Egwene said firmly. "If she can find us here, she can find us in Caemlyn, and she will."

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd sloʊli. "ɪf jə seɪ soʊ, bʌɾ ɪf ʃi dʌzn əpɪɹ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ɪn ə fju deɪz, wi ɡoʊ ɑn tə tɑɹ vəlɑn ən pʊɾ əɹ keɪs bɪfɔɹ ði æmɪɝlɪn sit." hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. tu wiks əɡoʊ jud nɛvɝ ivən sin ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən naʊ jəɹ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. laɪt! "əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə læn, ðɛɹz ə ɡʊd ɹoʊd fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn." hi lʊkt ət ði ɔɪl peɪpɝ pækət bɪsaɪɾ ɛɡwin ən klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "wʌt tʃæns ʌv ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz?"

Perrin nodded slowly. "If you say so, but if she doesn't appear in Caemlyn in a few days, we go on to Tar Valon and put our case before the Amyrlin Seat." He took a deep breath. Two weeks ago you'd never even seen an Aes Sedai, and now you're talking about the Amyrlin Seat. Light! "According to Lan, there's a good road from Caemlyn." He looked at the oiled paper packet beside Egwene and cleared his throat. "What chance of a little more bread and cheese?"

"ðɪs maɪɾ əv tə læst ə lɔŋ taɪm," ʃi sɛd, "ənlɛs juv bɛɾɝ lʌk wɪð snɛɹz ðən aɪ dɪd læs naɪt. ət lis ðə faɪɝ wɑz izi." ʃi læf sɔfli əz ɪf ʃi hæd meɪɾ ə dʒoʊk, tʌkɪŋ ðə pækət bæk ɪndə hɝ sæɾəlbæɡz.

"This might have to last a long time," she said, "unless you have better luck with snares than I did last night. At least the fire was easy." She laughed softly as if she had made a joke, tucking the packet back into her saddlebags.

əpɛɹənli ðəɹ wɝ lɪməts tə haʊ mʌtʃ liɾɝʃɪp ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə æksɛpt. hɪz stʌmək ɹʌmbəld. "ɪn ðət keɪs," hi sɛd, stændɪŋ, "wi maɪɾ əz wɛl stɑɹt naʊ."

Apparently there were limits to how much leadership she was willing to accept. His stomach rumbled. "In that case," he said, standing, "we might as well start now."

"bʌt jəɹ stɪl wɛt," ʃi pɹətɛstəd.

"But you're still wet," she protested.

"aɪl wɔk maɪsɛlf dʒɹaɪ," hi sɛd fɝmli, ən bɪɡæn kɪkɪŋ dɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə faɪɝ. ɪf i wɑz ðə liɾɝ, ɪt wɑz taɪm tə stɑɹt liɾɪŋ. ðə wɪn fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ wɑz pɪkɪŋ ʌp.

"I'll walk myself dry," he said firmly, and began kicking dirt over the fire. If he was the leader, it was time to start leading. The wind from the river was picking up.


tʃæptɝ twɛntiθɹi


CHAPTER 23

wʊlfbɹəðɝ


Wolfbrother

fɹəm ðə stɑɹt pɛɹɪn nu ðə dʒɝni tə keɪɛmlɪn wɑz gɑnə bi fɑɹ fɹəm kʌmftəɹbəl, bɪɡɪnɪŋ wɪð ɛɡwinz ɪnsɪstəns ðət ðeɪ teɪk tɝnz ɹaɪɾɪŋ bɛlə. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ fɑɹ ɪt wɑz, ʃi sɛd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tu fɑɹ fəɹ əɹ tə bi ði oʊnli wʌn u ɹoʊd. hɝ dʒɔ fɝmd, ən əɹ aɪz stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm ənblɪŋkɪŋ.

From the start Perrin knew the journey to Caemlyn was going to be far from comfortable, beginning with Egwene's insistence that they take turns riding Bela. They did not know how far it was, she said, but it was too far for her to be the only one who rode. Her jaw firmed, and her eyes stared at him unblinking.

"aɪm tu bɪɡ tə ɹaɪd bɛlə," hi sɛd. "aɪm juz tə wɔkɪŋ, ən aɪd ɹæðɝ."

"I'm too big to ride Bela," he said. "I'm used to walking, and I'd rather."

"æn aɪm nɑt juz tə wɔkɪŋ?" ɛɡwin sɛd ʃɑɹpli.

"And I am not used to walking?" Egwene said sharply.

"ðæɾ ɪzənt wʌɾ aɪ - "

"That isn't what I - "

"ɪm ði oʊnli wʌn huz səpoʊz tə ɡɛt sæɾəlsɔɹ, ɪz ðəɾ ɪt? ən wən jə wɔk tɪl jəɹ fiɾ ɑɹ ɹɛɾi tə fɔl ɔf, jəl ɪkspɛk mi tə lʊk æftɝ ju."

"I'm the only one who's supposed to get saddlesore, is that it? And when you walk till your feet are ready to fall off, you'll expect me to look after you."

"lɛɾ ɪt bi," hi bɹiðd wən ʃi lʊk laɪk ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. "ɛniweɪ, jəl teɪk ðə fɝs tɝn." hɝ feɪs tɝn ivən mɔɹ stʌbɝn, bʌɾ i ɹəfjuz tə lɛɾ əɹ ɡɛɾ ə wɝɾ ɪn ɛdʒwaɪz. "ɪf jə woʊnt ɡɛɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəl baɪ jɝsɛlf, əl pʊt jə ðɛɹ."

"Let it be," he breathed when she looked like going on. "Anyway, you'll take the first turn." Her face turned even more stubborn, but he refused to let her get a word in edgewise. "If you won't get in the saddle by yourself, I'll put you there."

ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə stɑɹɾəld lʊk, ən ə smɔl smaɪl kɝvd əɹ lɪps. "ɪn ðət keɪs. . . ." ʃi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ʃi wɝ əbaʊt tə læf, bʌt ʃi klaɪmd ʌp.

She gave him a startled look, and a small smile curved her lips. "In that case. . . ." She sounded as if she were about to laugh, but she climbed up.

hi ɡɹʌmbəl tə hɪmsɛlf əz i tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ. liɾɝz ɪn stɔɹiz nɛvɝ hæd tə pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ðɪs sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ.

He grumbled to himself as he turned away from the river. Leaders in stories never had to put up with this sort of thing.

ɛɡwin dɪɾ ɪnsɪst ɑn ɪm teɪkɪŋ ɪz tɝnz, ən wɛnɛvɝ i tʃɹaɪd tə əvɔɪɾ ɪt, ʃi bʊliɾ ɪm ɪndə ðə sæɾəl. blæksmɪθɪŋ dɪd nɑt lɛn ɪtsɛlf tə ə slɛndɝ bɪld, ən bɛlə wɑz nɑt vɛɹi lɑɹdʒ əz hɔɹsəz wɛnt. ɛvɹi taɪm i pʊɾ ɪz fʊɾ ɪn ðə stɝəp ðə ʃæɡi mɛɹ lʊkt əɾ ɪm wɪð wʌɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ wɑz ɹipɹoʊtʃ. smɔl θɪŋz, pɝhæps, bʌt ðeɪ ɪɹəteɪɾəd. sun i flɪntʃt wɛnɛvɝ ɛɡwin ənaʊnst, "ɪts jəɹ tɝn, pɛɹɪn."

Egwene did insist on him taking his turns, and whenever he tried to avoid it, she bullied him into the saddle. Blacksmithing did not lend itself to a slender build, and Bela was not very large as horses went. Every time he put his foot in the stirrup the shaggy mare looked at him with what he was sure was reproach. Small things, perhaps, but they irritated. Soon he flinched whenever Egwene announced, "It's your turn, Perrin."

ɪn stɔɹiz liɾɝz sɛldəm flɪntʃt, ən ðeɪ wɝ nɛvɝ bʊlid. bʌt, hi ɹəflɛktəd, ðeɪ nɛvɝ hæd tə dil wɪð ɛɡwin, iðɝ.

In stories leaders seldom flinched, and they were never bullied. But, he reflected, they never had to deal with Egwene, either.

ðəɹ wɝ oʊnli ʃɔɹt ɹæʃənz ə bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz tə bɪɡɪn wɪð, ən wʌt ðəɹ wɑz ɡeɪv aʊt baɪ ði ɛn ə ðə fɝs deɪ. pɛɹɪn sɛt snɛɹz əlɔŋ laɪkli ɹæbət ɹʌnz - ðeɪ lʊkt oʊld, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz wɝθ ə tʃæns - waɪl ɛɡwin bɪɡæn leɪɪŋ ə faɪɝ. wən i wɑz dʌn, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd tə tʃɹaɪ hɪz hænd wɪð ɪz slɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə laɪt feɪld ɔltəɡɛðɝ. ðeɪ hæd nɑt sin ə saɪn ʌv ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl əlaɪv, bʌt. . . . tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, hi dʒʌmpt ə skɹɔni ɹæbəɾ ɔlmoʊst ət wʌns. hi wɑz soʊ sɝpɹaɪzd wən ɪt bɝs fɹəm ʌndɝ ə bʊʃ ɹaɪt bɪniθ ɪz fit ðəɾ ɪɾ ɔlmoʊst ɡɑɾ əweɪ, bʌɾ i fɛtʃt ɪɾ ət fɔɹɾi peɪsɪz, dʒʌst əz ɪt wɑz dɑɹɾɪŋ ɝaʊn ə tʃɹi.

There were only short rations of bread and cheese to begin with, and what there was gave out by the end of the first day. Perrin set snares along likely rabbit runs - they looked old, but it was worth a chance - while Egwene began laying a fire. When he was done, he decided to try his hand with his sling before the light failed altogether. They had not seen a sign of anything at all alive, but. . . . To his surprise, he jumped a scrawny rabbit almost at once. He was so surprised when it burst from under a bush right beneath his feet that it almost got away, but he fetched it at forty paces, just as it was darting around a tree.

wən i keɪm bæk tə ðə kæmp wɪð ðə ɹæbət, ɛɡwin hæd bɹoʊkən lɪmz ɔl leɪd fəɹ ðə faɪɝ, bʌt ʃi wɑz nilɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə paɪl wɪð əɹ aɪz kloʊzd. "wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ? jə kænt wɪʃ ə faɪɝ."

When he came back to the camp with the rabbit, Egwene had broken limbs all laid for the fire, but she was kneeling beside the pile with her eyes closed. "What are you doing? You can't wish a fire."

ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ə dʒʌmp əɾ ɪz fɝst wɝdz, ən twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn tə stɛɹ əɾ ɪm wɪð ə hæn tə hɝ θɹoʊt. "ju . . . jə stɑɹɾəld mi."

Egwene gave a jump at his first words, and twisted around to stare at him with a hand to her throat. "You . . . you startled me."

"aɪ wɑz lʌki," hi sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹæbət. "ɡɛt jəɹ flɪn ən stil. wi it wɛl tənaɪt, ət list."

"I was lucky," he said, holding up the rabbit. "Get your flint and steel. We eat well tonight, at least."

"aɪ doʊn əv ə flɪnt," ʃi sɛd sloʊli. "ɪt wɑz ɪn maɪ pɑkət, ən aɪ lɔst ɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ."

"I don't have a flint," she said slowly. "It was in my pocket, and I lost it in the river."

"ðɛn haʊ . . . ?"

"Then how . . . ?"

"ɪt wɑz soʊ izi bæk ðəɹ ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk, pɛɹɪn. dʒʌs ðə weɪ mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ ʃoʊd mi. aɪ dʒʌst ɹitʃt aʊt, ænd. . . ." ʃi dʒɛstʃɝɾ əz ɪf ɡɹæspɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ, ðən lɛɾ əɹ hæn fɔl wɪð ə saɪ. "aɪ kæn faɪn ɪt, naʊ."

"It was so easy back there on the riverbank, Perrin. Just the way Moiraine Sedai showed me. I just reached out, and. . . ." She gestured as if grasping for something, then let her hand fall with a sigh. "I can't find it, now."

pɛɹɪn lɪkt ɪz lɪps ənizəli. "ðə . . . ðə paʊɝ?" ʃi nɑɾəd, ən i stɛɹɾ ət hɝ. "ɑɹ jə kɹeɪzi? aɪ min . . . ðə wʌn paʊɝ! jə kæn dʒʌs pleɪ ɝaʊnd wɪð sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðæt."

Perrin licked his lips uneasily. "The . . . the Power?" She nodded, and he stared at her. "Are you crazy? I mean . . . the One Power! You can't just play around with something like that."

"ɪt wɑz soʊ izi, pɛɹɪn. aɪ kən də ɪt. aɪ kən tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ."

"It was so easy, Perrin. I can do it. I can channel the Power."

hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "aɪl meɪk ə faɪɝboʊ, ɛɡwin. pɹɑməs jə woʊn tʃɹaɪ ðɪs . . . ðɪs . . . θɪŋ əɡɛn."

He took a deep breath. "I'll make a firebow, Egwene. Promise you won't try this . . . this . . . thing again."

"aɪ wɪl nɑt." hɝ dʒɔ fɝmd ɪn ə weɪ ðət meɪɾ ɪm saɪ. "wʊd jə ɡɪv ʌp ðəɾ æks ə jʊɹz, pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə? wəd jə wɔk ɝaʊnd wɪð wʌn hæn taɪd bɪhaɪn jəɹ bæk? aɪ woʊn də ɪt!"

"I will not." Her jaw firmed in a way that made him sigh. "Would you give up that axe of yours, Perrin Aybara? Would you walk around with one hand tied behind your back? I won't do it!"

"aɪl meɪk ðə faɪɝboʊ," hi sɛd wɛɹəli. "æt list, doʊn tʃɹaɪ ɪɾ əɡɛn tənaɪt? pliz?"

"I'll make the firebow," he said wearily. "At least, don't try it again tonight? Please?"

ʃi ækwiɛst ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli, ən ivən æftɝ ðə ɹæbət wɑz ɹoʊstɪŋ ɑn ə spɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə fleɪmz, hi hæd ðə filɪŋ ʃi fɛlt ʃi cʊɾə dʌn ɪt bɛɾɝ. ʃi wəd nɑt ɡɪv ʌp tʃɹaɪɪŋ, iðɝ, ɛvɹi naɪt, ðoʊ ðə bɛst ʃi ɛvɝ dɪd wɑz ə tʃɹɪkəl ə smoʊk ðət vænɪʃt ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli. hɝ aɪz dɛɹɾ ɪm tə seɪ ə wɝd, ən i waɪzli kɛpt ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt.

She acquiesced grudgingly, and even after the rabbit was roasting on a spit over the flames, he had the feeling she felt she could have done it better. She would not give up trying, either, every night, though the best she ever did was a trickle of smoke that vanished almost immediately. Her eyes dared him to say a word, and he wisely kept his mouth shut.

æftɝ ðət wʌn hɑt mil, ðeɪ səbsɪstɪɾ ɑn kɔɹs waɪl təbɝz ən ə fju jʌŋ ʃuts. wɪð stɪl noʊ saɪn ə spɹɪŋ, nʌn ʌv ɪt wɑz plɛntəfəl, ən nʌn ʌv ɪt teɪsti, iðɝ. niðɝ kəmpleɪnd, bʌt nɑɾ ə mil pæst wɪθaʊt wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ saɪɪŋ ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli, ən ðeɪ boʊθ nu ɪt wɑz fəɹ ðə tæŋ ʌv ə bɪɾ ə tʃiz, əɹ ivən ðə smɛl ə bɹɛd. ə faɪn ə mʌʃɹumz - kwinz kɹaʊnz, ðə bɛst - wʌn æftɝnun ɪn ə ʃeɪɾi pɑɹɾ ə ðə fɔɹəst wɑz ɪnʌf tə sim ə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹit. ðeɪ ɡɑbəld əm daʊn, læfɪŋ ən tɛlɪŋ stɔɹiz fɹəm bæk ɪn ɛmənz fild, stɔɹiz ðət bɪɡæn, "du jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ wən - " bʌt ðə mʌʃɹumz dɪd nɑt læs lɔŋ, ən niðɝ dɪd ðə læftɝ. ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl mɝθ ɪn hʌŋɡɝ.

After that one hot meal, they subsisted on coarse wild tubers and a few young shoots. With still no sign of spring, none of it was plentiful, and none of it tasty, either. Neither complained, but not a meal passed without one or the other sighing regretfully, and they both knew it was for the tang of a bit of cheese, or even the smell of bread. A find of mushrooms - Queen's Crowns, the best - one afternoon in a shady part of the forest was enough to seem a great treat. They gobbled them down, laughing and telling stories from back in Emond's Field, stories that began, "Do you remember when - " but the mushrooms did not last long, and neither did the laughter. There was little mirth in hunger.

wɪtʃɛvɝ wɑz wɔkɪŋ kæɹiɾ ə slɪŋ, ɹɛɾi tə lɛt flaɪ ət ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə ɹæbəɾ əɹ skwɝəl, bʌt ði oʊnli taɪm iðɝ hɝld ə stoʊn wɑz ɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. ðə snɛɹz ðeɪ sɛt soʊ kɛɹfəli itʃ ivnɪŋ jildəd nʌθɪŋ ət dɔn, ən ðeɪ dɪd nɑt dɛɹ steɪ ə deɪ ɪn wʌn pleɪs tə liv ðə snɛɹz aʊt. niðɝ ə ðɛm nu haʊ fɑɹ ɪt wɑz tə keɪɛmlɪn, ən niðɝ wəd fil seɪf əntɪl ðeɪ ɡɑt ðɛɹ, ɪf ðɛn. pɛɹɪn bɪɡæn tə wʌndɝ ɪf ɪz stʌmək kəd ʃɹɪŋk ɪnʌf tə meɪk ə hoʊl ɔl ðə weɪ θɹu hɪz mɪɾəl.

Whichever was walking carried a sling, ready to let fly at the sight of a rabbit or squirrel, but the only time either hurled a stone was in frustration. The snares they set so carefully each evening yielded nothing at dawn, and they did not dare stay a day in one place to leave the snares out. Neither of them knew how far it was to Caemlyn, and neither would feel safe until they got there, if then. Perrin began to wonder if his stomach could shrink enough to make a hole all the way through his middle.

ðeɪ meɪd ɡʊd taɪm, əz i sɔ ɪt, bʌɾ əz ðeɪ ɡɑt fɑɹðɝ ən fɑɹðɝ fɹəm ði ɑɹɪnɛl wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ə vɪlədʒ, əɹ ivən ə fɑɹmhaʊs wɛɹ ðeɪ kəɾ æsk dɝɛkʃənz, hɪz daʊts əbaʊɾ ɪz oʊn plæn ɡɹu. ɛɡwin kəntɪnjud tə əpɪɹ aʊtwɝdli əz kɑnfəɾənt əz wən ðeɪ sɛɾ aʊt, bʌɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ʃi wəd seɪ ɪt wʊɾə bɪn bɛɾɝ tə ɹɪsk ðə tʃɹɑləks ðən tə wɑndɝ ɝaʊn lɔs fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛɹ lɪvz. ʃi nɛvɝ dɪd, bʌɾ i kɛpt ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɪt.

They made good time, as he saw it, but as they got farther and farther from the Arinelle without seeing a village, or even a farmhouse where they could ask directions, his doubts about his own plan grew. Egwene continued to appear outwardly as confident as when they set out, but he was sure that sooner or later she would say it would have been better to risk the Trollocs than to wander around lost for the rest of their lives. She never did, but he kept expecting it.

tu deɪz fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ ðə læn tʃeɪnʒd tə θɪkli fɔɹəstəd hɪlz, əz ɡɹɪp baɪ ðə teɪl ɛn ʌv wɪntɝ əz ɛvɹiwɛɹ ɛls, ən ə deɪ æftɝ ðət ðə hɪlz flæɾənd aʊɾ əɡɛn, ðə dɛns fɔɹəs bɹoʊkən baɪ ɡleɪdz, ɔfən ə maɪl əɹ mɔɹ əkɹɔs. snoʊ stɪl leɪ ɪn hɪɾən hɑloʊz, ən ði ɛɹ wɑz bɹɪsk ʌv ə mɔɹnɪŋ, ən ðə wɪn koʊld ɔlweɪz. noʊwɛɹ dɪd ðeɪ si ə ɹoʊd, əɹ ə plaʊd fild, əɹ tʃɪmni smoʊk ɪn ðə dɪstəns, əɹ ɛni ʌðɝ saɪn ə hjumən hæbəteɪʃən - ət list, nʌn wɛɹ mɛn stɪl dwɛlt.

Two days from the river the land changed to thickly forested hills, as gripped by the tail end of winter as everywhere else, and a day after that the hills flattened out again, the dense forest broken by glades, often a mile or more across. Snow still lay in hidden hollows, and the air was brisk of a morning, and the wind cold always. Nowhere did they see a road, or a plowed field, or chimney smoke in the distance, or any other sign of human habitation - at least, none where men still dwelt.

wʌns ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ə tɔl stoʊn ɹæmpɑɹts ɪnsɝkəld ə hɪltɑp. pɑɹts ə ɹufləs stoʊn haʊsəz stʊɾ ɪnsaɪd ðə fɔlən sɝkəl. ðə fɔɹəs hæd lɔŋ swɑloʊɾ ɪt; tʃɹiz ɡɹu ɹaɪt θɹu ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ən spaɪɾɝwɛbz ʌv oʊl kɹipɝ ɛnvɛləp ðə bɪɡ stoʊn blɑks. ənʌðɝ taɪm ðeɪ keɪm ɑn ə stoʊn taʊɝ, bɹoʊkən-tɑpt ən bɹaʊn wɪð oʊl mɔs, linɪŋ ɑn ðə hjudʒ oʊk huz θɪk ɹuts wɝ sloʊli tɑpəlɪŋ ɪt. bʌt ðeɪ faʊnd noʊ pleɪs wɛɹ mɛn hæd bɹiðd ɪn lɪvɪŋ ɹimɛmbɹəns. mɛmɹiz ə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ kɛpt əm əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹuənz ən hɝid ðɛɹ fʊtstɛps əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ wʌns mɔɹ dip ɪn pleɪsəz ðət sim nɛvɝ tə hæv noʊn ə hjumən fʊtstɛp.

Once the remains of tall stone ramparts encircled a hilltop. Parts of roofless stone houses stood inside the fallen circle. The forest had long swallowed it; trees grew right through everything, and spiderwebs of old creeper enveloped the big stone blocks. Another time they came on a stone tower, broken-topped and brown with old moss, leaning on the huge oak whose thick roots were slowly toppling it. But they found no place where men had breathed in living remembrance. Memories of Shadar Logoth kept them away from the ruins and hurried their footsteps until they were once more deep in places that seemed never to have known a human footstep.

dʒɹimz pleɪɡd pɛɹɪnz slip, fɪɹfəl dʒɹimz. bælzəmən wɑz ɪn ðɛm, tʃeɪsɪŋ ɪm θɹu meɪzɪz, hʌntɪŋ hɪm, bʌt pɛɹɪn nɛvɝ mɛɾ ɪm feɪs-tə-feɪs, soʊ fɑɹ əz i ɹɪmɛmbɝd. ən ðɛɹ dʒɝni hæd bɪn ɪnʌf tə bɹɪŋ ə fju bæd dʒɹimz. ɛɡwin kəmpleɪn ə naɪtmɛɹz əbaʊt ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, ɪspɛʃli ðə tu naɪts æftɝ ðeɪ faʊn ðə ɹuən fɔɹɾ ən ði əbændən taʊɝ. pɛɹɪn kɛpt ɪz oʊn kaʊnsəl ivən wən i woʊk swɛɾɪŋ ən ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹk. ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ tə hɪm tə liɾ əm seɪfli tə keɪɛmlɪn, nɑt ʃɛɹ wɝiz əbaʊt wɪtʃ ðeɪ kəd də nʌθɪŋ.

Dreams plagued Perrin's sleep, fearful dreams. Ba'alzamon was in them, chasing him through mazes, hunting him, but Perrin never met him face-to-face, so far as he remembered. And their journey had been enough to bring a few bad dreams. Egwene complained of nightmares about Shadar Logoth, especially the two nights after they found the ruined fort and the abandoned tower. Perrin kept his own counsel even when he woke sweating and shaking in the dark. She was looking to him to lead them safely to Caemlyn, not share worries about which they could do nothing.

hi wɑz wɔkɪŋ ət bɛləz hɛd, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ðeɪ wəd faɪn ɛniθɪŋ tə it ðɪs ivnɪŋ, wən i fɝs kɑt ðə smɛl. ðə mɛɹ flɛɹɾ əɹ nɑstʃɹəlz ən swʌŋ əɹ hɛɾ ɪn ðə nɛks moʊmənt. hi sizd əɹ bɹaɪɾəl bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd wɪkɝ.

He was walking at Bela's head, wondering if they would find anything to eat this evening, when he first caught the smell. The mare flared her nostrils and swung her head in the next moment. He seized her bridle before she could whicker.

"ðæts smoʊk," ɛɡwin sɛɾ ɪksaɪɾədli. ʃi lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəl, dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. "ə kʊkfaɪɝ. sʌmbɑɾi ɪz ɹoʊstɪŋ dɪnɝ. ɹæbət."

"That's smoke," Egwene said excitedly. She leaned forward in the saddle, drew a deep breath. "A cookfire. Somebody is roasting dinner. Rabbit."

"meɪbi," pɛɹɪn sɛd kɔʃəsli, ən əɹ iɡɝ smaɪl feɪɾəd. hi ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɪz slɪŋ fəɹ ðə wɪkəd hæf-mun ə ði æks. hɪz hænz oʊpən ən kloʊzd ənsɝteɪnli ɑn ðə θɪk hæft. ɪt wɑz ə wɛpən, bʌt niðɝ ɪz hɪɾən pɹæktəs bɪhaɪn ðə fɔɹdʒ nɔɹ lænz titʃɪŋz hæd ɹɪli pɹipɛɹɾ ɪm tə juz ɪɾ əz wʌn. ivən ðə bæɾəl bɪfɔɹ ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ wɑz tu veɪɡ ɪn ɪz maɪn tə ɡɪv ɪm ɛni kɑnfəɾəns. hi kəd nɛvɝ kwaɪt mænədʒ ðət vɔɪd ðət ɹænd ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ tɔkt əbaʊt, iðɝ.

"Maybe," Perrin said cautiously, and her eager smile faded. He exchanged his sling for the wicked half-moon of the axe. His hands opened and closed uncertainly on the thick haft. It was a weapon, but neither his hidden practice behind the forge nor Lan's teachings had really prepared him to use it as one. Even the battle before Shadar Logoth was too vague in his mind to give him any confidence. He could never quite manage that void that Rand and the Warder talked about, either.

sʌnlaɪt slæntəd θɹu ðə tʃɹiz bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ən ðə fɔɹəst wɑz ə stɪl mæs ə dæpəld ʃædoʊz. ðə feɪn smɛl ʌv wʊdzmoʊk dʒɹɪftəɾ ɝaʊn ðɛm, tɪŋd wɪð ði ɝoʊmə ʌv kʊkɪŋ mit. ɪt kəd bi ɹæbət, hi θɔt, ən ɪz stʌmək ɡɹʌmbəld. ən ɪt kəd bi sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, hi ɹimaɪndəd hɪmsɛlf. hi lʊkt əɾ ɛɡwin; ʃi wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm. ðəɹ wɝ ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾiz tə biɪŋ liɾɝ.

Sunlight slanted through the trees behind them, and the forest was a still mass of dappled shadows. The faint smell of woodsmoke drifted around them, tinged with the aroma of cooking meat. It could be rabbit, he thought, and his stomach grumbled. And it could be something else, he reminded himself. He looked at Egwene; she was watching him. There were responsibilities to being leader.

"weɪt hɪɹ," hi sɛd sɔfli. ʃi fɹaʊnd, bʌɾ i kʌɾ əɹ ɔf əz ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ. "æn bi kwaɪət! wi doʊnt noʊ hu ɪɾ ɪz, jɛt." ʃi nɑɾəd. ɹɪlʌktənli, bʌt ʃi dɪɾ ɪt. pɛɹɪn wʌndɝd waɪ ðət dɪd nɑt wɝk wən i wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk əɹ teɪk ɪz tɝn ɹaɪɾɪŋ. dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hi stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə sɔɹs ə ðə smoʊk.

"Wait here," he said softly. She frowned, but he cut her off as she opened her mouth. "And be quiet! We don't know who it is, yet." She nodded. Reluctantly, but she did it. Perrin wondered why that did not work when he was trying to make her take his turn riding. Drawing a deep breath, he started for the source of the smoke.

hi hæd nɑt spɛn əz mʌtʃ taɪm ɪn ðə fɔɹəsts ɝaʊn ɛmənz fild əz ɹænd əɹ mæt, bʌt stɪl i hæd dʌn ɪz ʃɛɹ ə hʌntɪŋ ɹæbəts. hi kɹɛp fɹəm tʃɹi tə tʃɹi wɪθaʊt soʊ mʌtʃ əz snæpɪŋ ə twɪɡ. ɪt wɑz nɑt lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ i wɑz piɹɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə boʊl ʌv ə tɔl oʊk wɪð spɹɛɾɪŋ, sɝpəntaɪn lɪmz ðət bɛn tə tʌtʃ ðə ɡɹaʊn ðən ɹoʊz əɡɛn. bɪɑn leɪ ə kæmpfaɪɝ, ən ə lin, sʌn-bɹaʊn mæn wɑz linɪŋ əɡɛnst wʌn ə ðə lɪmz nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ðə fleɪmz.

He had not spent as much time in the forests around Emond's Field as Rand or Mat, but still he had done his share of hunting rabbits. He crept from tree to tree without so much as snapping a twig. It was not long before he was peering around the bole of a tall oak with spreading, serpentine limbs that bent to touch the ground then rose again. Beyond lay a campfire, and a lean, sun-browned man was leaning against one of the limbs not far from the flames.

ət list i wɑz nɑɾ ə tʃɹɑlɑk, bʌɾ i wɑz ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɪst fɛloʊ pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ, hɪz kloʊðz ɔl sim tə bi meɪd fɹəm ænəməl skɪnz, wɪð ðə fɝ stɪl ɑn, ivən ɪz buts ən ði ɑd, flæt-tɑpt ɹaʊn kæp ɑn ɪz hɛd. hɪz kloʊk wɑz ə kɹeɪzi kwɪlt ə ɹæbəɾ ən skwɝəl; hɪz tʃɹaʊzɝz əpɪɹd tə bi meɪd fɹəm ðə lɔŋ-hɛɹd haɪɾ ʌv ə bɹaʊn ən waɪt ɡoʊt. ɡæðɝɾ ət ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk wɪð ə kɔɹd, hɪz ɡɹeɪɪŋ bɹaʊn hɛɹ hʌŋ tə hɪz weɪst. ə θɪk bɪɹd fæn əkɹɔs hæf ɪz tʃɛst. ə lɔŋ naɪf hʌŋ əɾ ɪz bɛlt, ɔlmoʊst ə sɔɹd, ən ə baʊ ən kwɪvɝ stʊd pɹɑpt əɡɛnst ə lɪm kloʊs tə hænd.

At least he was not a Trolloc, but he was the strangest fellow Perrin had ever seen. For one thing, his clothes all seemed to be made from animal skins, with the fur still on, even his boots and the odd, flat-topped round cap on his head. His cloak was a crazy quilt of rabbit and squirrel; his trousers appeared to be made from the long-haired hide of a brown and white goat. Gathered at the back of his neck with a cord, his graying brown hair hung to his waist. A thick beard fanned across half his chest. A long knife hung at his belt, almost a sword, and a bow and quiver stood propped against a limb close to hand.

ðə mæn lin bæk wɪð ɪz aɪz kloʊzd, əpɛɹənli əslip, bʌt pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt stɝ fɹəm ɪz kənsilmənt. sɪks stɪks slæntəɾ oʊvɝ ðə fɛloʊz faɪɝ, ən ɑn itʃ stɪk ə ɹæbət wɑz skjuɝd, ɹoʊstəd bɹaʊn ən naʊ ən ðən dʒɹɪpɪŋ dʒus ðət hɪst ɪn ðə fleɪmz. ðə smɛl ə ðɛm, soʊ kloʊs, meɪɾ ɪz maʊθ wɔɾɝ.

The man leaned back with his eyes closed, apparently asleep, but Perrin did not stir from his concealment. Six sticks slanted over the fellow's fire, and on each stick a rabbit was skewered, roasted brown and now and then dripping juice that hissed in the flames. The smell of them, so close, made his mouth water.

"ju dʌn dʒɹulɪŋ?" ðə mæn oʊpənd wʌn aɪ ən kɑkt ɪɾ ət pɛɹɪnz haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs. "ju ən jəɹ fɹɛn maɪɾ əz wɛl sɪɾ ən əv ə baɪt. aɪ hævən sin jə it mʌtʃ ðə læs kʌpəl ə deɪz."

"You done drooling?" The man opened one eye and cocked it at Perrin's hiding place. "You and your friend might as well sit and have a bite. I haven't seen you eat much the last couple of days."

pɛɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən stʊd sloʊli, stɪl ɡɹɪpɪŋ ɪz æks taɪtli. "juv bɪn wɑtʃɪŋ mi fəɹ tu deɪz?"

Perrin hesitated, then stood slowly, still gripping his axe tightly. "You've been watching me for two days?"

ðə mæn tʃʌkəl dip ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt. "jɛs, aɪ bɪn wɑtʃɪŋ ju. ən ðət pɹɪɾi ɡɝl. pʊʃəz jə ɝaʊn laɪk ə bæntəm ɹustɝ, dʌznt ʃi? hɝd ju, moʊsli. ðə hɔɹs ɪz ði oʊnli wʌn ə jə dʌzn tʃɹæmpəl ɝaʊn laʊɾ ɪnʌf tə bi hɝd faɪv maɪlz ɔf. jə gɑnə æsk əɹ ɪn, əɹ ɑɹ jə ɪntɛndɪŋ tə iɾ ɔl ðə ɹæbət jɝsɛlf?"

The man chuckled deep in his throat. "Yes, I been watching you. And that pretty girl. Pushes you around like a bantam rooster, doesn't she? Heard you, mostly. The horse is the only one of you doesn't trample around loud enough to be heard five miles off. You going to ask her in, or are you intending to eat all the rabbit yourself?"

pɛɹɪn bɹɪsəld; hi nu hi dɪd nɑt meɪk mʌtʃ nɔɪz. jə kəd nɑt ɡɛt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə ə ɹæbəɾ ɪn ðə wɔɾɝwʊd tə fɛtʃ ɪt wɪð ə slɪŋ ɪf jə meɪd nɔɪz. bʌt ðə smɛl ə ɹæbət meɪɾ ɪm ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz hʌŋɡɹi, tu, nɑt tə mɛnʃən weɪɾɪŋ tə dɪskʌvɝ ɪf ɪt wɑz ə tʃɹɑlɑk faɪɝ ðeɪ hæd smɛld.

Perrin bristled; he knew he did not make much noise. You could not get close enough to a rabbit in the Waterwood to fetch it with a sling if you made noise. But the smell of rabbit made him remember that Egwene was hungry, too, not to mention waiting to discover if it was a Trolloc fire they had smelled.

hi slɪp ðə hæft ə hɪz æks θɹu ðə bɛlt lup ən ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs. "ɛɡwin! ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt! ɪts ɹæbət!" ɔfɝɪŋ ɪz hænd, hi æɾəd ɪn ə mɔɹ nɔɹməl toʊn, "maɪ neɪm ɪz pɛɹɪn. pɛɹɪn eɪbɑɹə."

He slipped the haft of his axe through the belt loop and raised his voice. "Egwene! It's all right! It is rabbit!" Offering his hand, he added in a more normal tone, "My name is Perrin. Perrin Aybara."

ðə mæn kənsɪɾɝd ɪz hæn bɪfɔɹ teɪkɪŋ ɪɾ ɔkwɝdli, əz ɪf ənjuz tə ʃeɪkɪŋ hænz. "aɪm kɔld ɛlaɪəs," hi sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ʌp. "ɛlaɪəs mækɛɹə."

The man considered his hand before taking it awkwardly, as if unused to shaking hands. "I'm called Elyas," he said, looking up. "Elyas Machera."

pɛɹɪn ɡæspt, ən nɪɹli dʒɹɑpt ɛlaɪəsəz hænd. ðə mænz aɪz wɝ jɛloʊ, laɪk bɹaɪt, pɑlɪʃt ɡoʊld. səm mɛmɹi tɪkəld ət ðə bæk ə pɛɹɪnz maɪnd, ðən flɛd. ɔl i kəd θɪŋk ə ɹaɪt ðən wɑz ðəɾ ɔl ə ðə tʃɹɑləks' aɪz i hæd sin hæd bɪn ɔlmoʊs blæk.

Perrin gasped, and nearly dropped Elyas's hand. The man's eyes were yellow, like bright, polished gold. Some memory tickled at the back of Perrin's mind, then fled. All he could think of right then was that all of the Trollocs' eyes he had seen had been almost black.

ɛɡwin əpɪɹd, kɔʃəsli liɾɪŋ bɛlə. ʃi taɪd ðə mɛɹz ɹeɪnz tə wʌn ə ðə smɔlɝ bɹæntʃəz ə ði oʊk, ən meɪd pəlaɪt saʊnz wən pɛɹɪn ɪntʃɹədust əɹ tə ɛlaɪəs, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz kɛp dʒɹɪftɪŋ tə ðə ɹæbəts. ʃi dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs ðə mænz aɪz. wən ɛlaɪəs moʊʃən əm tə ðə fud, ʃi fɛl tə wɪð ə wɪl. pɛɹɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli ə mɪnət lɔŋɡɝ bɪfɔɹ dʒɔɪnɪŋ hɝ.

Egwene appeared, cautiously leading Bela. She tied the mare's reins to one of the smaller branches of the oak, and made polite sounds when Perrin introduced her to Elyas, but her eyes kept drifting to the rabbits. She did not seem to notice the man's eyes. When Elyas motioned them to the food, she fell to with a will. Perrin hesitated only a minute longer before joining her.

ɛlaɪəs weɪɾəd saɪlənli waɪl ðeɪ eɪt. pɛɹɪn wɑz soʊ hʌŋɡɹi hi tɔɹ ɔf pisəz ə mit soʊ hɑɾ i hæd tə dʒʌɡəl əm fɹəm hæn tə hæn bɪfɔɹ i kəd hoʊld əm ɪn ɪz maʊθ. ivən ɛɡwin ʃoʊd lɪɾəl ə hɝ juʒəwəl nitnəs; ɡɹisi dʒus ɹæn daʊn əɹ tʃɪn. deɪ feɪɾəd ɪndə twaɪlaɪt bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə sloʊ daʊn, munləs dɑɹknəs kloʊzɪŋ ɪn ɝaʊn ðə faɪɝ, ən ðən ɛlaɪəs spoʊk.

Elyas waited silently while they ate. Perrin was so hungry he tore off pieces of meat so hot he had to juggle them from hand to hand before he could hold them in his mouth. Even Egwene showed little of her usual neatness; greasy juice ran down her chin. Day faded into twilight before they began to slow down, moonless darkness closing in around the fire, and then Elyas spoke.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ aʊt hɪɹ? ðəɹ ɪzən ə haʊs ɪnsaɪd fɪfti maɪlz ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən."

"What are you doing out here? There isn't a house inside fifty miles in any direction."

"wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "pɝhæps jə kəd - " hɝ aɪbɹaʊz lɪftəd kuli əz ɛlaɪəs θɹu bæk ɪz hɛɾ ən ɹɔɹd wɪð læftɝ. pɛɹɪn stɛɹɾ ət hɪm, ə ɹæbət lɛɡ hæf ɹeɪz tə hɪz maʊθ.

"We're going to Caemlyn," Egwene said. "Perhaps you could - " Her eyebrows lifted coolly as Elyas threw back his head and roared with laughter. Perrin stared at him, a rabbit leg half raised to his mouth.

"keɪɛmlɪn?" ɛlaɪəs wizd wən i kəd tɔk əɡɛn. "ðə pæθ jəɹ fɑloʊɪŋ, ðə laɪn juv teɪkən ðə læs tu deɪz, jəl pæs ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz əɹ mɔɹ nɔɹθ ə keɪɛmlɪn."

"Caemlyn?" Elyas wheezed when he could talk again. "The path you're following, the line you've taken the last two days, you'll pass a hundred miles or more north of Caemlyn."

"wi wɝ gɑnə æsk dɝɛkʃənz," ɛɡwin sɛd dɪfɛnsɪvli. "wi dʒʌs hævən faʊn ɛni vɪlədʒəz əɹ fɑɹmz, jɛt."

"We were going to ask directions," Egwene said defensively. "We just haven't found any villages or farms, yet."

"ænd nʌn jə wɪl," ɛlaɪəs sɛd, tʃʌklɪŋ. "ðə weɪ jəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ, jə kən tʃɹævəl ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld wɪθaʊt siɪŋ ənʌðɝ hjumən. ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf jə mænədʒ tə klaɪm ðə spaɪn - ɪt kən bi dʌn, səm pleɪsəz - jə kəd faɪn pipəl ɪn ði il weɪst, bʌt jə wʊdn laɪk ɪt ðɛɹ. jud bɹɔɪl baɪ deɪ, ən fɹiz baɪ naɪt, ən daɪ ʌv θɝst ɛnitaɪm. ɪt teɪks ən ilmən tə faɪnd wɔɾɝ ɪn ðə weɪst, ən ðeɪ doʊn laɪk stʃɹeɪnʒɝz mʌtʃ. noʊ, nɑt mʌtʃ, aɪd seɪ." hi sɛɾ ɔf ɪndə ənʌðɝ, mɔɹ fjʊɹiəs, bɝst ə læftɝ, ðɪs taɪm æktʃəli  ɹoʊlɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. "nɑt mʌtʃ əɾ ɔl," hi mænədʒd.

"And none you will," Elyas said, chuckling. "The way you're going, you can travel all the way to the Spine of the World without seeing another human. Of course, if you managed to climb the Spine - it can be done, some places - you could find people in the Aiel Waste, but you wouldn't like it there. You'd broil by day, and freeze by night, and die of thirst anytime. It takes an Aielman to find water in the Waste, and they don't like strangers much. No, not much, I'd say." He set off into another, more furious, burst of laughter, this time actually rolling on the ground. "Not much at all," he managed.

pɛɹɪn ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli. ɑɹ wi iɾɪŋ wɪð ə mædmæn?

Perrin shifted uneasily. Are we eating with a madman?

ɛɡwin fɹaʊnd, bʌt ʃi weɪɾəd əntɪl ɛlaɪəsəz mɝθ feɪɾəd ə lɪɾəl, ðən sɛd, "pɝhæps jə kəd ʃoʊ əs ðə weɪ. jə sim tə noʊ ə ɡʊd dil mɔɹ əbaʊt wɛɹ pleɪsəz ɑɹ ðən wi du."

Egwene frowned, but she waited until Elyas's mirth faded a little, then said, "Perhaps you could show us the way. You seem to know a good deal more about where places are than we do."

ɛlaɪəs stɑp læfɪŋ. ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hɛd, hi ɹipleɪst ɪz ɹaʊn fɝ kæp, wɪtʃ hæd fɔlən ɔf waɪl i wɑz ɹoʊlɪŋ əbaʊt, ən stɛɹɾ əɾ əɹ fɹəm ʌndɝ loʊɝd bɹaʊz. "aɪ doʊn mʌtʃ laɪk pipəl," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs. "sɪɾiz ɑɹ fʊl ə pipəl. aɪ doʊnt ɡoʊ nɪɹ vɪlədʒəz, əɹ ivən fɑɹmz, vɛɹi ɔfən. vɪlɪdʒɝz, fɑɹmɝz, ðeɪ doʊn laɪk maɪ fɹɛnz. aɪ wʊdn ivən əv hɛlp jə ɪf jə hædn bɪn stʌmbəlɪŋ ɝaʊn əz hɛlpləs ən ɪnəsən əz nubɔɹn kʌbz."

Elyas stopped laughing. Raising his head, he replaced his round fur cap, which had fallen off while he was rolling about, and stared at her from under lowered brows. "I don't much like people," he said in a flat voice. "Cities are full of people. I don't go near villages, or even farms, very often. Villagers, farmers, they don't like my friends. I wouldn't even have helped you if you hadn't been stumbling around as helpless and innocent as newborn cubs."

"bʌɾ ət lis jə kən tɛl əs wɪtʃ weɪ tə ɡoʊ," ʃi ɪnsɪstəd. "ɪf jə dɝɛkt əs tə ðə nɪɹəs vɪlədʒ, ivən ɪf ɪts fɪfti maɪlz əweɪ, ʃʊɹli ðəl ɡɪv əs dɝɛkʃənz tə keɪɛmlɪn."

"But at least you can tell us which way to go," she insisted. "If you direct us to the nearest village, even if it's fifty miles away, surely they'll give us directions to Caemlyn."

"bi stɪl," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. "maɪ fɹɛnz ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ."

"Be still," Elyas said. "My friends are coming."

bɛlə sʌɾənli wɪniɾ ɪn fɪɹ, ən bɪɡæn dʒɝkɪŋ tə pʊl əɹ ɹeɪnz fɹi. pɛɹɪn hæf ɹoʊz əz ʃeɪps əpɪɹɾ ɔl ɝaʊn əm ɪn ðə dɑɹkənɪŋ fɔɹəst. bɛlə ɹɪɹɾ ən twɪstəd, skɹimɪŋ.

Bela suddenly whinnied in fear, and began jerking to pull her reins free. Perrin half rose as shapes appeared all around them in the darkening forest. Bela reared and twisted, screaming.

"kwaɪət ðə mɛɹ," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. "ðeɪ woʊn hɝt hɝ. əɹ ju, ɪf jəɹ stɪl."

"Quiet the mare," Elyas said. "They won't hurt her. Or you, if you're still."

fɔɹ wʊlvz stɛpt ɪndə ðə faɪɹlaɪt, ʃæɡi, weɪst-haɪ fɔɹmz wɪð dʒɔz ðət kəd bɹeɪk ə mænz lɛɡ. əz ɪf ðə pipəl wɝ nɑt ðəɹ ðeɪ wɔkt ʌp tə ðə faɪɝ ən leɪ daʊn bɪtwin ðə hjumənz. ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs əmʌŋ ðə tʃɹiz faɪɹlaɪt ɹəflɛktəɾ ɔf ði aɪz ə mɔɹ wʊlvz, ɑn ɔl saɪdz.

Four wolves stepped into the firelight, shaggy, waist-high forms with jaws that could break a man's leg. As if the people were not there they walked up to the fire and lay down between the humans. In the darkness among the trees firelight reflected off the eyes of more wolves, on all sides.

jɛloʊ aɪz, pɛɹɪn θɔt. laɪk ɛlaɪəsəz aɪz. ðət wɑz wʌɾ i hæd bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ. kɛɹfəli wɑtʃɪŋ ðə wʊlvz əmʌŋ ðɛm, hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz æks.

Yellow eyes, Perrin thought. Like Elyas's eyes. That was what he had been trying to remember. Carefully watching the wolves among them, he reached for his axe.

"aɪ wəd nɑt də ðæt," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. "ɪf ðeɪ θɪŋk jə min hɑɹm, ðəl stɑp biɪŋ fɹɛnli."

"I would not do that," Elyas said. "If they think you mean harm, they'll stop being friendly."

ðeɪ wɝ stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm, ðoʊz fɔɹ wʊlvz, pɛɹɪn sɔ. hi hæd ðə filɪŋ ðəɾ ɔl ðə wʊlvz, ðoʊz ɪn ðə tʃɹiz, əz wɛl, wɝ stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm. ɪt meɪɾ ɪz skɪn ɪtʃ. kɔʃəsli hi muvd ɪz hænz əweɪ fɹəm ði æks. hi ɪmædʒən i kəd fil ðə tɛnʃən iz əmʌŋ ðə wʊlvz. sloʊli hi sæt bæk daʊn; hɪz hænz ʃʊk əntɪl i ɡɹɪpt ɪz niz tə stɑp ðɛm. ɛɡwin wɑz soʊ stɪf ʃi ɔlmoʊs kwɪvɝd. wʌn wʊlf, kloʊs tə blæk wɪð ə laɪɾɝ ɡɹeɪ pætʃ ɑn ɪz feɪs, leɪ nɪɹli tʌtʃɪŋ hɝ.

They were staring at him, those four wolves, Perrin saw. He had the feeling that all the wolves, those in the trees, as well, were staring at him. It made his skin itch. Cautiously he moved his hands away from the axe. He imagined he could feel the tension ease among the wolves. Slowly he sat back down; his hands shook until he gripped his knees to stop them. Egwene was so stiff she almost quivered. One wolf, close to black with a lighter gray patch on his face, lay nearly touching her.

bɛlə hæd sist əɹ skɹimɪŋ ən ɹɪɹɪŋ. ɪnstɛd ʃi stʊd tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ ən ʃɪftɪŋ ɪn ən ətɛmp tə kip ɔl ə ðə wʊlvz ɪn vju, kɪkɪŋ əkeɪʒənəli tə ʃoʊ ðə wʊlvz ðət ʃi kʊd, ɪntɛndɪŋ tə sɛl əɹ laɪf dɪɹli. ðə wʊlvz sim tə ɪɡnɔɹ əɹ ən ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. tʌŋz lɑlɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ maʊðz, ðeɪ weɪɾəd ət ðɛɹ iz.

Bela had ceased her screaming and rearing. Instead she stood trembling and shifting in an attempt to keep all of the wolves in view, kicking occasionally to show the wolves that she could, intending to sell her life dearly. The wolves seemed to ignore her and everyone else. Tongues lolling out of their mouths, they waited at their ease.

"ðɛɹ," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. "ðæts bɛɾɝ."

"There," Elyas said. "That's better."

"ɑɹ ðeɪ teɪm?" ɛɡwin æsk feɪnli, ən hoʊpfəli, tu. "ðeɪɹ . . . pɛts?"

"Are they tame?" Egwene asked faintly, and hopefully, too. "They're . . . pets?"

ɛlaɪəs snɔɹɾɪd. "wʊlvz doʊn teɪm, ɡɝl, nɑɾ ivən əz wɛl əz mɛn. ðəɹ maɪ fɹɛnz. wi kip itʃ ʌðɝ kʌmpəni, hʌn təɡɛðɝ, kɑnvɝs, æftɝ ə fæʃən. dʒʌs laɪk ɛni fɹɛnz. ɪzən ðət ɹaɪt, dæpəl?" ə wʊlf wɪð fɝ ðət feɪɾəd θɹu ə dʌzən ʃeɪdz ʌv ɡɹeɪ, dɑɹk ən laɪt, tɝn əɹ hɛd tə lʊk ət hɪm.

Elyas snorted. "Wolves don't tame, girl, not even as well as men. They're my friends. We keep each other company, hunt together, converse, after a fashion. Just like any friends. Isn't that right, Dapple?" A wolf with fur that faded through a dozen shades of gray, dark and light, turned her head to look at him.

"ju tɔk tə ðɛm?" pɛɹɪn mɑɹvəld.

"You talk to them?" Perrin marveled.

"ɪɾ ɪzən ɪɡzækli tɔkɪŋ," ɛlaɪəs ɹɪplaɪd sloʊli. "ðə wɝdz doʊn mæɾɝ, ən ðeɪ ɑɹən ɪɡzækli ɹaɪt, iðɝ. hɝ neɪm ɪzən dæpəl. ɪts sʌmθɪŋ ðət minz ðə weɪ ʃædoʊz pleɪ ɑn ə fɔɹəs pul əɾ ə mɪdwɪntɝ dɔn, wɪð ðə bɹiz ɹɪpəlɪŋ ðə sɝfəs, ən ðə tæŋ ʌv aɪs wən ðə wɔɾɝ tʌtʃəz ðə tʌŋ, ən ə hɪn ə snoʊ bɪfɔɹ naɪtfɔl ɪn ði ɛɹ. bʌt ðəɾ ɪzən kwaɪɾ ɪt, iðɝ. jə kæn seɪ ɪɾ ɪn wɝdz. ɪts mɔɹ ʌv ə filɪŋ. ðæts ðə weɪ wʊlvz tɔk. ði ʌðɝz ɑɹ bɝn, hɑpɝ, ən wɪnd." bɝn hæɾ ən oʊl skɑɹ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ðət maɪɾ ɪkspleɪn ɪz neɪm, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ əbaʊt ði ʌðɝ tu wʊlvz tə ɡɪv ɛni ɪndəkeɪʃən ʌv wʌt ðɛɹ neɪmz maɪt min.

"It isn't exactly talking," Elyas replied slowly. "The words don't matter, and they aren't exactly right, either. Her name isn't Dapple. It's something that means the way shadows play on a forest pool at a midwinter dawn, with the breeze rippling the surface, and the tang of ice when the water touches the tongue, and a hint of snow before nightfall in the air. But that isn't quite it, either. You can't say it in words. It's more of a feeling. That's the way wolves talk. The others are Burn, Hopper, and Wind." Burn had an old scar on his shoulder that might explain his name, but there was nothing about the other two wolves to give any indication of what their names might mean.

fəɹ ɔl ðə mænz ɡɹʌfnəs, pɛɹɪn θɔɾ ɛlaɪəs wɑz pliz tə hæv ðə tʃæns tə tɔk tə ənʌðɝ hjumən. hi simd iɡɝ ɪnʌf tə də ɪt, ət list. pɛɹɪn aɪd ðə wʊlvz' tiθ ɡlɪsnɪŋ ɪn ðə faɪɹlaɪɾ ən θɔɾ ɪt maɪt bi ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə tə kip ɪm tɔkɪŋ. "haʊ . . . haʊ dɪd jə lɝn tə tɔk tə wʊlvz, ɛlaɪəs?"

For all the man's gruffness, Perrin thought Elyas was pleased to have the chance to talk to another human. He seemed eager enough to do it, at least. Perrin eyed the wolves' teeth glistening in the firelight and thought it might be a good idea to keep him talking. "How . . . how did you learn to talk to wolves, Elyas?"

"ðeɪ faʊn aʊt," ɛlaɪəs ɹɪplaɪd, "aɪ dɪdnt. nɑɾ ət fɝst. ðæts ɔlweɪz ðə weɪ ʌv ɪt, aɪ ʌndɝstænd. ðə wʊlvz faɪn ju, nɑt jə ðɛm. səm pipəl θɔt mi tʌtʃt baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn, kəz wʊlvz stɑɹɾəd əpɪɹɪŋ wɛɹɛvɝ aɪ wɛnt. aɪ səpoʊz aɪ θɔt soʊ, tu, səmtaɪmz. moʊs disən foʊk bɪɡæn tə əvɔɪd mi, ən ðə wʌnz u sɔt mi aʊt wɝn ðə kaɪn aɪ wɑntəd tə noʊ, wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ. ðən aɪ noʊɾəst ðəɹ wɝ taɪmz wən ðə wʊlvz sim tə noʊ wʌɾ aɪ wɑz θɪŋkɪŋ, tə ɹɪspɑn tə wʌt wɑz ɪn maɪ hɛd. ðət wɑz ðə ɹil bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ðeɪ wɝ kjʊɹiəs əbaʊt mi. wʊlvz kən sɛns pipəl, juʒəwəli, bʌt nɑt laɪk ðɪs. ðeɪ wɝ ɡlæd tə faɪn mi. ðeɪ seɪ ɪts bɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm sɪns ðeɪ hʌntəd wɪð mɛn, ən wən ðeɪ seɪ ə lɔŋ taɪm, ðə filɪŋ aɪ ɡɛɾ ɪz laɪk ə koʊld wɪn haʊlɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ daʊn fɹəm ðə fɝs deɪ."

"They found out," Elyas replied, "I didn't. Not at first. That's always the way of it, I understand. The wolves find you, not you them. Some people thought me touched by the Dark One, because wolves started appearing wherever I went. I suppose I thought so, too, sometimes. Most decent folk began to avoid me, and the ones who sought me out weren't the kind I wanted to know, one way or another. Then I noticed there were times when the wolves seemed to know what I was thinking, to respond to what was in my head. That was the real beginning. They were curious about me. Wolves can sense people, usually, but not like this. They were glad to find me. They say it's been a long time since they hunted with men, and when they say a long time, the feeling I get is like a cold wind howling all the way down from the First Day."

"aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə mɛn hʌntɪŋ wɪð wʊlvz," ɛɡwin sɛd. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli stɛɾi, bʌt ðə fæk ðət ðə wʊlvz wɝ dʒʌs laɪɪŋ ðəɹ sim tə ɡɪv əɹ hɑɹt.

"I never heard of men hunting with wolves," Egwene said. Her voice was not entirely steady, but the fact that the wolves were just lying there seemed to give her heart.

ɪf ɛlaɪəs hɝd hɝ, hi ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn. "wʊlvz ɹɪmɛmbɝ θɪŋz dɪfɹənli fɹəm ðə weɪ pipəl du," hi sɛd. hɪz stʃɹeɪnʒ aɪz tʊk ɑn ə fɑɹəweɪ lʊk, əz ɪf i wɝ dʒɹɪftɪŋ ɔf ɑn ðə floʊ ʌv mɛmɹi hɪmsɛlf. "ɛvɹi wʊlf ɹɪmɛmbɝz ðə hɪstɝi ʌv ɔl wʊlvz, əɹ ət lis ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ɪt. laɪk aɪ sɛd, ɪt kæn bi pʊɾ ɪndə wɝdz vɛɹi wɛl. ðeɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn pɹeɪ saɪd-baɪ-saɪd wɪð mɛn, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz soʊ lɔŋ əɡoʊ ðəɾ ɪts mɔɹ laɪk ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ə ʃædoʊ ðən ə mɛmɹi."

If Elyas heard her, he gave no sign. "Wolves remember things differently from the way people do," he said. His strange eyes took on a faraway look, as if he were drifting off on the flow of memory himself. "Every wolf remembers the history of all wolves, or at least the shape of it. Like I said, it can't be put into words very well. They remember running down prey side-by-side with men, but it was so long ago that it's more like the shadow of a shadow than a memory."

"ðæts vɛɹi ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ," ɛɡwin sɛd, ən ɛlaɪəs lʊkt əɾ əɹ ʃɑɹpli. "noʊ, aɪ min ɪt. ɪɾ ɪz." ʃi wɛɾ əɹ lɪps. "kʊd . . . ɑ . . . kəd jə titʃ əs tə tɔk tə ðɛm?"

"That's very interesting," Egwene said, and Elyas looked at her sharply. "No, I mean it. It is." She wet her lips. "Could . . . ah . . . could you teach us to talk to them?"

ɛlaɪəs snɔɹɾɪd əɡɛn. "ɪt kæn bi tɔt. səm kən də ɪt, səm kænt. ðeɪ seɪ hi kæn." hi pɔɪntəɾ ət pɛɹɪn.

Elyas snorted again. "It can't be taught. Some can do it, some can't. They say he can." He pointed at Perrin.

pɛɹɪn lʊkt əɾ ɛlaɪəsəz fɪŋɡɝ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ə naɪf. hi ɹɪli ɪz ə mædmæn. ðə wʊlvz wɝ stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm əɡɛn. hi ʃɪftəɾ ənkʌmftəbli.

Perrin looked at Elyas's finger as if it were a knife. He really is a madman. The wolves were staring at him again. He shifted uncomfortably.

"ju seɪ jəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn," ɛlaɪəs sɛd, "bʌt ðət stɪl dʌzn ɪkspleɪn wʌt jəɹ duɪŋ aʊt hɪɹ, deɪz fɹəm ɛniwɛɹ." hi tɔs bæk ɪz fɝ-pætʃ kloʊk ən leɪ daʊn ɑn ɪz saɪd, pɹɑpt ɑn wʌn ɛlboʊ ən weɪɾɪŋ ɪkspɛktənli.

"You say you're going to Caemlyn," Elyas said, "but that still doesn't explain what you're doing out here, days from anywhere." He tossed back his fur-patch cloak and lay down on his side, propped on one elbow and waiting expectantly.

pɛɹɪn ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin. ɝli ɑn ðeɪ hæd kənkɑktəɾ ə stɔɹi fəɹ wən ðeɪ faʊn pipəl, tə ɪkspleɪn wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ wɪθaʊt bɹɪŋɪŋ əm ɛni tʃɹʌbəl. wɪθaʊt lɛɾɪŋ ɛniwʌn noʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɹɪli fɹʌm, əɹ wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɹɪli ɡoʊɪŋ, ɪvɛntʃəwəli. hu nu wʌt kɛɹləs wɝd maɪt ɹitʃ ə feɪdz ɪɹ? ðeɪ hæd wɝkt ɑn ɪɾ ɛvɹi deɪ, pætʃɪŋ ɪt təɡɛðɝ, hoʊnɪŋ aʊt flɔz. ən ðeɪ hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd ɛɡwin wɑz ðə wʌn tə tɛl ɪt. ʃi wɑz bɛɾɝ wɪð wɝdz ðən i wɑz, ən ʃi kleɪmd ʃi kəɾ ɔlweɪz tɛl wən i wɑz laɪɪŋ baɪ hɪz feɪs.

Perrin glanced at Egwene. Early on they had concocted a story for when they found people, to explain where they were going without bringing them any trouble. Without letting anyone know where they were really from, or where they were really going, eventually. Who knew what careless word might reach a Fade's ear? They had worked on it every day, patching it together, honing out flaws. And they had decided Egwene was the one to tell it. She was better with words than he was, and she claimed she could always tell when he was lying by his face.

ɛɡwin bɪɡæn ət wʌns, smuðli. ðeɪ wɝ fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ, fɹəm sɑldɑiə, fɹəm fɑɹmz aʊtsaɪɾ ə taɪni vɪlədʒ. niðɝ ə ðɛm hæd bɪn mɔɹ ðən twɛnti maɪlz fɹəm hoʊm ɪn ðɛɹ hoʊl lɪvz bɪfɔɹ ðɪs. bʌt ðeɪ hæd hɝd ɡlimənz stɔɹiz, ən mɝtʃəns' teɪlz, ən ðeɪ wɑntəd tə si səm ə ðə wɝld. keɪɛmlɪn, ən ɪljən. ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, ən meɪbi ivən ðə feɪbəld aɪlənz ə ðə si foʊk.

Egwene began at once, smoothly. They were from the north, from Saldaea, from farms outside a tiny village. Neither of them had been more than twenty miles from home in their whole lives before this. But they had heard gleemen's stories, and merchants' tales, and they wanted to see some of the world. Caemlyn, and Illian. The Sea of Storms, and maybe even the fabled islands of the Sea Folk.

pɛɹɪn lɪsənd wɪð sæɾəsfækʃən. nɑɾ ivən tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn cʊɾə meɪɾ ə bɛɾɝ teɪl fɹəm ðə lɪɾəl ðeɪ nu ʌv ðə wɝld aʊtsaɪd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, əɹ wʌn bɛɾɝ suɾəd tə ðɛɹ nidz.

Perrin listened with satisfaction. Not even Thom Merrilin could have made a better tale from the little they knew of the world outside the Two Rivers, or one better suited to their needs.

"fɹʌm sɑldɑiə, ɛ?" ɛlaɪəs sɛd wən ʃi wɑz dʌn.

"From Saldaea, eh?" Elyas said when she was done.

pɛɹɪn nɑɾəd. "ðæts ɹaɪt. wi θɔɾ əbaʊt siɪŋ mɛɹədɑn fɝst. aɪd ʃʊɹli laɪk tə si ðə kɪŋ. bʌt ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi wəd bi ðə fɝs pleɪs əɹ fɑðɝz wəd lʊk."

Perrin nodded. "That's right. We thought about seeing Maradon first. I'd surely like to see the King. But the capital city would be the first place our fathers would look."

ðət wɑz ɪz pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt, tə meɪk ɪt pleɪn ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn tə mɛɹədɑn. ðət weɪ noʊ wʌn wəɾ ɪkspɛkt əm tə noʊ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə sɪɾi, dʒʌst ɪn keɪs ðeɪ ɹæn ɪndə sʌmwʌn u ɹɪli hæd bɪn ðɛɹ. ɪt wɑz ɔl ə lɔŋ weɪ fɹəm ɛmənz fild ən ði ɪvɛns ʌv wɪntɝnaɪt. noʊbɑdi hɪɹɪŋ ðə teɪl wəɾ əv ɛni ɹizən tə θɪŋk ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, əɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

That was his part of it, to make it plain they had never been to Maradon. That way no one would expect them to know anything about the city, just in case they ran into someone who really had been there. It was all a long way from Emond's Field and the events of Winternight. Nobody hearing the tale would have any reason to think of Tar Valon, or Aes Sedai.

"kwaɪɾ ə stɔɹi." ɛlaɪəs nɑɾəd. "jɛs, kwaɪɾ ə stɔɹi. ðɛɹz ə fju θɪŋz ɹɔŋ wɪð ɪt, bʌt ðə meɪn θɪŋ ɪz dæpəl sɛz ɪts ɔl ə lʌmp ə laɪz. ɛvɹi læst wɝd."

"Quite a story." Elyas nodded. "Yes, quite a story. There's a few things wrong with it, but the main thing is Dapple says it's all a lump of lies. Every last word."

"laɪz!" ɛɡwin ɪkskleɪmd. "waɪ wəd wi laɪ?"

"Lies!" Egwene exclaimed. "Why would we lie?"

ðə fɔɹ wʊlvz hæd nɑt muvd, bʌt ðeɪ noʊ lɔŋɡɝ sim tə bi dʒʌs laɪɪŋ ðəɹ ɝaʊn ðə faɪɝ; ðeɪ kɹaʊtʃt, ɪnstɛd, ən ðɛɹ jɛloʊ aɪz wɑtʃt ði ɛmənz fildɝz wɪθaʊt blɪŋkɪŋ.

The four wolves had not moved, but they no longer seemed to be just lying there around the fire; they crouched, instead, and their yellow eyes watched the Emond's Fielders without blinking.
