pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt seɪ ɛniθɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪz hæn stʃɹeɪd tə ði æks əɾ ɪz weɪst. ðə fɔɹ wʊlvz ɹoʊz tə ðɛɹ fiɾ ɪn wʌn kwɪk muvmənt, ən ɪz hæn fɹoʊz. ðeɪ meɪd noʊ saʊnd, bʌt ðə θɪk hækəlz ɑn ðɛɹ nɛks stʊɾ ɪɹɛkt. wʌn ə ðə wʊlvz bæk ʌndɝ ðə tʃɹiz ɹeɪzd ə ɡɹoʊlɪŋ haʊl ɪndə ðə naɪt. ʌðɝz ænsɝd, faɪv, tɛn, twɛnti, tɪl ðə dɑɹknəs ɹɪpəld wɪð ðɛm. əbɹʌpli ðeɪ, tu, wɝ stɪl. koʊl swɛt tʃɹɪkəl daʊn pɛɹɪnz feɪs.

Perrin did not say anything, but his hand strayed to the axe at his waist. The four wolves rose to their feet in one quick movement, and his hand froze. They made no sound, but the thick hackles on their necks stood erect. One of the wolves back under the trees raised a growling howl into the night. Others answered, five, ten, twenty, till the darkness rippled with them. Abruptly they, too, were still. Cold sweat trickled down Perrin's face.

"ɪf jə θɪŋk. . . ." ɛɡwin stɑp tə swɑloʊ. dɪspaɪt ðə tʃɪl ɪn ði ɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz swɛɾ ɑn əɹ feɪs, tu. "ɪf jə θɪŋk wəɹ laɪɪŋ, ðən jəl pɹɑbli pɹəfɝ ðət wi meɪk əɹ oʊn kæmp fəɹ ðə naɪt, əweɪ fɹəm jʊɹz."

"If you think. . . ." Egwene stopped to swallow. Despite the chill in the air there was sweat on her face, too. "If you think we are lying, then you'll probably prefer that we make our own camp for the night, away from yours."

"ɔɹɾənɛɹəli aɪ wʊd, ɡɝl. bʌt ɹaɪt naʊ aɪ wɑnə noʊ əbaʊt ðə tʃɹɑləks. ən ðə hæfmən." pɛɹɪn stʃɹʌɡəl tə kip ɪz feɪs ɪmpæsɪv, ən hoʊpt i wɑz duɪŋ bɛɾɝ əɾ ɪt ðən ɛɡwin. ɛlaɪəs wɛn ɑn ɪn ə kɑnvɝseɪʃənəl toʊn. "dæpəl sɛz ʃi smɛl hæfmən ən tʃɹɑləks ɪn jəɹ maɪnz waɪl jə wɝ tɛlɪŋ ðət ful stɔɹi. ðeɪ ɔl dɪd. jəɹ mɪkst ʌp wɪð tʃɹɑləks, sʌmhaʊ, ən ði aɪləs. wʊlvz heɪt tʃɹɑləks ən hæfmən wɝs ðən waɪldfaɪɝ, wɝs ðən ɛniθɪŋ, ən soʊ də aɪ.

"Ordinarily I would, girl. But right now I want to know about the Trollocs. And the Halfmen." Perrin struggled to keep his face impassive, and hoped he was doing better at it than Egwene. Elyas went on in a conversational tone. "Dapple says she smelled Halfmen and Trollocs in your minds while you were telling that fool story. They all did. You're mixed up with Trollocs, somehow, and the Eyeless. Wolves hate Trollocs and Halfmen worse than wildfire, worse than anything, and so do I.

"bɝn wɑns tə bi dʌn wɪð ju. ɪt wɑz tʃɹɑləks ɡeɪv ɪm ðət mɑɹk wən i wɑz ə jɝlɪŋ. hi sɛz ɡeɪm ɪz skɛɹs, ən jəɹ fæɾɝ ðən ɛni dɪɹ hiz sin ɪn mʌnθs, ən wi ʃəd bi dʌn wɪð ju. bʌt bɝn ɪz ɔlweɪz ɪmpeɪʃənt. waɪ doʊn jə tɛl mi əbaʊɾ ɪt? aɪ hoʊp jəɹ nɑt dɑɹkfɹɛnz. aɪ doʊn laɪk kɪlɪŋ pipəl æftɝ aɪv fɛd ðɛm. dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ðəl noʊ ɪf jə laɪ, ən ivən dæpəl ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi nɪɹ əz əpsɛɾ əz bɝn." hɪz aɪz, əz jɛloʊ əz ðə wʊlvz' aɪz, blɪŋk noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðɛɹz dɪd. ðeɪ ɑɹ ə wʊlfs aɪz, pɛɹɪn θɔt.

"Burn wants to be done with you. It was Trollocs gave him that mark when he was a yearling. He says game is scarce, and you're fatter than any deer he's seen in months, and we should be done with you. But Burn is always impatient. Why don't you tell me about it? I hope you're not Darkfriends. I don't like killing people after I've fed them. Just remember, they'll know if you lie, and even Dapple is already near as upset as Burn." His eyes, as yellow as the wolves' eyes, blinked no more than theirs did. They are a wolf's eyes, Perrin thought.

ɛɡwin wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, hi ɹilaɪzd, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə dɪsaɪd wʌt ðeɪ ʃəd du. laɪt, sʌɾənli ɪm ðə liɾɝ əɡɛn. ðeɪ hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd fɹəm ðə fɝs ðət ðeɪ kəd nɑt ɹɪsk tɛlɪŋ ðə ɹil stɔɹi tə ɛniwʌn, bʌɾ i sɔ noʊ tʃæns fəɹ əm tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ ivən ɪf i mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ɪz æks aʊt bɪfɔɹ. . . .

Egwene was looking at him, he realized, waiting for him to decide what they should do. Light, suddenly I'm the leader again. They had decided from the first that they could not risk telling the real story to anyone, but he saw no chance for them to get away even if he managed to get his axe out before. . . .

dæpəl ɡɹaʊl dip ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt, ən ðə saʊnd wɑz teɪkən ʌp baɪ ði ʌðɝ θɹi ɝaʊn ðə faɪɝ, ðən baɪ ðə wʊlvz ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. ðə mɛnəsɪŋ ɹʌmbəl fɪl ðə naɪt.

Dapple growled deep in her throat, and the sound was taken up by the other three around the fire, then by the wolves in the darkness. The menacing rumble filled the night.

"ɔl ɹaɪt," pɛɹɪn sɛd kwɪkli. "ɔl ɹaɪt!" ðə ɡɹoʊlɪŋ kʌɾ ɔf, ʃɑɹp ən sʌɾən. ɛɡwin ənklɛntʃt əɹ hænz ən nɑɾəd. "ɪɾ ɔl stɑɹɾəd ə fju deɪz bɪfɔɹ wɪntɝnaɪt," pɛɹɪn bɪɡæn, "wɛn əɹ fɹɛn mæt sɔ ə mæn ɪn ə blæk kloʊk. . . ."

"All right," Perrin said quickly. "All right!" The growling cut off, sharp and sudden. Egwene unclenched her hands and nodded. "It all started a few days before Winternight," Perrin began, "when our friend Mat saw a man in a black cloak. . . ."

ɛlaɪəs nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd ɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən əɹ ðə weɪ hi leɪ ɑn ɪz saɪd, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə tɪlt ə hɪz hɛd ðət spoʊk ʌv ɪɹz pɹɪkɪŋ ʌp. ðə fɔɹ wʊlvz sæt daʊn əz pɛɹɪn wɛn ɑn; hi hæd ði ɪmpɹɛʃən ðeɪ wɝ lɪsnɪŋ, tu. ðə stɔɹi wɑz ə lɔŋ wʌn, ən i toʊld ɔlmoʊst ɔl ʌv ɪt. ðə dʒɹim i ən ði ʌðɝz hæd hæɾ ɪn bɛɹlən, ðoʊ, hi kɛp tə hɪmsɛlf. hi weɪɾəd fəɹ ðə wʊlvz tə meɪk səm saɪn ðeɪ hæd kɑt ði oʊmɪʃən, bʌt ðeɪ oʊnli wɑtʃt. dæpəl sim fɹɛnli, bɝn æŋɡɹi. hi wɑz hɔɹs baɪ ðə taɪm i fɪnɪʃt.

Elyas never changed his expression or the way he lay on his side, but there was something about the tilt of his head that spoke of ears pricking up. The four wolves sat down as Perrin went on; he had the impression they were listening, too. The story was a long one, and he told almost all of it. The dream he and the others had had in Baerlon, though, he kept to himself. He waited for the wolves to make some sign they had caught the omission, but they only watched. Dapple seemed friendly, Burn angry. He was hoarse by the time he finished.

". . . ən ɪf ʃi dʌzn faɪn əs ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, wɪl ɡoʊ ɑn tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. wi doʊn əv ɛni tʃɔɪs ɪksɛp tə ɡɛt hɛlp fɹəm ði ɛɛs sədaɪ."

". . . and if she doesn't find us in Caemlyn, we'll go on to Tar Valon. We don't have any choice except to get help from the Aes Sedai."

"tʃɹɑləks ən hæfmən ðɪs fɑɹ saʊθ," ɛlaɪəs mjuzd. "naʊ ðæts sʌmθɪŋ tə kənsɪɾɝ." hi ɹuɾəd bɪhaɪn ɪm ən tɔs pɛɹɪn ə haɪd wɔɾɝbæɡ, nɑt ɹɪli lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. hi əpɪɹd tə bi θɪŋkɪŋ. hi weɪɾəd əntɪl pɛɹɪn hæd dʒɹʌŋk ən ɹipleɪs ðə plʌɡ bɪfɔɹ i spoʊk əɡɛn. "aɪ doʊn hoʊld wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, ðoʊz ðət laɪk hʌntɪŋ fəɹ mɛn u mɛs wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ðeɪ wɑntəd tə dʒɛntəl mi, wʌns. aɪ toʊld əm tə ðɛɹ feɪsəz ðeɪ wɝ blæk ədʒɑ; sɝv ðə dɑɹk wʌn, aɪ sɛd, ən ðeɪ dɪdn laɪk ðəɾ əɾ ɔl. ðeɪ kʊdn kætʃ mi, ðoʊ, wʌns aɪ ɡɑɾ ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd tʃɹaɪ. jɛs, ðeɪ dɪd. kʌm tə ðæt, aɪ daʊɾ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd teɪk kaɪnli tə mi, æftɝ ðæt. aɪ hæd tə kɪl ə kʌpəl ʌv wɔɹɾɝz. bæd bɪznəs, ðæt, kɪlɪŋ wɔɹɾɝz. doʊn laɪk ɪt."

"Trollocs and Halfmen this far south," Elyas mused. "Now that's something to consider." He rooted behind him and tossed Perrin a hide waterbag, not really looking at him. He appeared to be thinking. He waited until Perrin had drunk and replaced the plug before he spoke again. "I don't hold with Aes Sedai. The Red Ajah, those that like hunting for men who mess with the One Power, they wanted to gentle me, once. I told them to their faces they were Black Ajah; served the Dark One, I said, and they didn't like that at all. They couldn't catch me, though, once I got into the forest, but they did try. Yes, they did. Come to that, I doubt any Aes Sedai would take kindly to me, after that. I had to kill a couple of Warders. Bad business, that, killing Warders. Don't like it."

"ðɪs tɔkɪŋ tə wʊlvz," pɛɹɪn sɛɾ ənizəli. "ɪt . . . ɪts tə də wɪð ðə paʊɝ?"

"This talking to wolves," Perrin said uneasily. "It . . . it has to do with the Power?"

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt," ɛlaɪəs ɡɹaʊld. "wʊdn əv wɝkt ɑn mi, dʒɛntəlɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt meɪd mi mæd, ðɛm wɑntɪŋ tə tʃɹaɪ. ðɪs ɪz ən oʊl θɪŋ, bɔɪ. oʊldɝ ðən ɛɛs sədaɪ. oʊldɝ ðən ɛnibəɾi juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ. oʊld əz hjumənkaɪnd. oʊld əz wʊlvz. ðeɪ doʊn laɪk ðəɾ iðɝ, ɛɛs sədaɪ. oʊl θɪŋz kʌmɪŋ əɡɛn. aɪm nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn. ðəɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝ θɪŋz, ʌðɝ foʊk. meɪks ɛɛs sədaɪ nɝvəs, meɪks əm mʌɾɝ əbaʊɾ eɪntʃən bæɹiɝz wikənɪŋ. θɪŋz ɑɹ bɹeɪkɪŋ əpɑɹt, ðeɪ seɪ. ðəɹ əfɹeɪd ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɪl ɡɛt lus, ɪz wʌt. jud θɪŋk aɪ wɑz tə bleɪm, ðə weɪ səm ə ðɛm lʊkt ət mi. ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, ɛniweɪ, bʌt səm ʌðɝz, tu. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit. . . . ɑə! aɪ kip klɪɹ ə ðɛm, moʊsli, ən klɪɹ ə fɹɛnz ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, əz wɛl. jə wɪl, tu, ɪf jəɹ smɑɹt."

"Of course not," Elyas growled. "Wouldn't have worked on me, gentling, but it made me mad, them wanting to try. This is an old thing, boy. Older than Aes Sedai. Older than anybody using the One Power. Old as humankind. Old as wolves. They don't like that either, Aes Sedai. Old things coming again. I'm not the only one. There are other things, other folk. Makes Aes Sedai nervous, makes them mutter about ancient barriers weakening. Things are breaking apart, they say. They're afraid the Dark One will get loose, is what. You'd think I was to blame, the way some of them looked at me. Red Ajah, anyway, but some others, too. The Amyrlin Seat. . . . Aaaah! I keep clear of them, mostly, and clear of friends of Aes Sedai, as well. You will, too, if you're smart."

"aɪd laɪk nʌθɪŋ bɛɾɝ ðən tə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm ɛɛs sədaɪ," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"I'd like nothing better than to stay away from Aes Sedai," Perrin said.

ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ɪm ə ʃɑɹp lʊk. hi hoʊpt ʃi wəd nɑt bɝst aʊt ðət ʃi wɑntəd tə bi ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. bʌt ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ, ðoʊ hɝ maʊθ taɪɾənd, ən pɛɹɪn wɛn ɑn.

Egwene gave him a sharp look. He hoped she would not burst out that she wanted to be an Aes Sedai. But she said nothing, though her mouth tightened, and Perrin went on.

"ɪɾ ɪzən əz ɪf wɪv ə tʃɔɪs. wiv hæd tʃɹɑləks tʃeɪsɪŋ ʌs, ən feɪdz, ən dʒɹæɡkɝ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ bʌt dɑɹkfɹɛnz. wi kæn haɪd, ən wi kæn faɪt bæk əloʊn. soʊ hu ɪz gɑnə hɛlp ʌs? hu ɛls ɪz stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf, ɪksɛpt ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

"It isn't as if we have a choice. We've had Trollocs chasing us, and Fades, and Draghkar. Everything but Darkfriends. We can't hide, and we can't fight back alone. So who is going to help us? Who else is strong enough, except Aes Sedai?"

ɛlaɪəs wɑz saɪlən fəɹ ə taɪm, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə wʊlvz, moʊst ɔfən ət dæpəl əɹ bɝn. pɛɹɪn ʃɪftəd nɝvəsli ən tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə wɑtʃ. wən i wɑtʃt i hæd ðə filɪŋ ðəɾ i kəɾ ɔlmoʊs hɪɹ wʌɾ ɛlaɪəs ən ðə wʊlvz wɝ seɪɪŋ tə wʌn ənʌðɝ. ivən ɪf ɪt hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə paʊɝ, hi wɑntəd noʊ pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. hi hæd tə bi meɪkɪŋ səm kɹeɪzi dʒoʊk. aɪ kæn tɔk tə wʊlvz. wʌn ə ðə wʊlvz - hɑpɝ, hi θɔt - lʊkt əɾ ɪm ən sim tə ɡɹɪn. hi wʌndɝd haʊ hi hæd pʊɾ ə neɪm tə hɪm.

Elyas was silent for a time, looking at the wolves, most often at Dapple or Burn. Perrin shifted nervously and tried not to watch. When he watched he had the feeling that he could almost hear what Elyas and the wolves were saying to one another. Even if it had nothing to do with the Power, he wanted no part of it. He had to be making some crazy joke. I can't talk to wolves. One of the wolves - Hopper, he thought - looked at him and seemed to grin. He wondered how he had put a name to him.

"ju kəd steɪ wɪð mi," ɛlaɪəs sɛd faɪnəli. "wɪð ʌs." ɛɡwinz aɪbɹaʊz ʃɑɾ ʌp, ən pɛɹɪnz maʊθ dʒɹɑpt oʊpən. "wɛl, wʌt kəd bi seɪfɝ?" ɛlaɪəs tʃælənʒd. "tʃɹɑləks wɪl teɪk ɛni tʃæns ðeɪ ɡɛt tə kɪl ə wʊlf baɪ ɪtsɛlf, bʌt ðəl ɡoʊ maɪlz aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ weɪ tə əvɔɪɾ ə pæk. ən jə woʊn əv tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, iðɝ. ðeɪ doʊn ɔfən kʌm ɪndə ðiz wʊdz."

"You could stay with me," Elyas said finally. "With us." Egwene's eyebrows shot up, and Perrin's mouth dropped open. "Well, what could be safer?" Elyas challenged. "Trollocs will take any chance they get to kill a wolf by itself, but they'll go miles out of their way to avoid a pack. And you won't have to worry about Aes Sedai, either. They don't often come into these woods."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ." pɛɹɪn əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət ðə wʊlvz tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm. wʌn wɑz dæpəl, ən i kəd fil əɹ aɪz ɑn hɪm. "fɔɹ wʌn θɪŋ, ɪɾ ɪzən dʒʌs ðə tʃɹɑləks."

"I don't know." Perrin avoided looking at the wolves to either side of him. One was Dapple, and he could feel her eyes on him. "For one thing, it isn't just the Trollocs."

ɛlaɪəs tʃʌkəl koʊldli. "aɪv sin ə pæk pʊl daʊn wʌn ə ði aɪləs, tu. lɔs hæf ðə pæk, bʌt ðeɪ wʊdnt ɡɪv ʌp wʌns ðeɪ hæɾ ɪts sɛnt. tʃɹɑləks, mɹdʒɹɑl, ɪts ɔl wʌn tə ðə wʊlvz. ɪts jə ðeɪ ɹɪli wɑnt, bɔɪ. ðeɪv hɝɾ ʌv ʌðɝ mɛn u kən tɔk tə wʊlvz, bʌt jəɹ ðə fɝs ðeɪv ɛvɝ mɛt bɪsaɪdz mi. ðəl æksɛp jəɹ fɹɛnd, tu, ðoʊ, ən jəl ɔl bi seɪfɝ hɪɹ ðən ɪn ɛni sɪɾi. ðɛɹz dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪn sɪɾiz."

Elyas chuckled coldly. "I've seen a pack pull down one of the Eyeless, too. Lost half the pack, but they wouldn't give up once they had its scent. Trollocs, Myrddraal, it's all one to the wolves. It's you they really want, boy. They've heard of other men who can talk to wolves, but you're the first they've ever met besides me. They'll accept your friend, too, though, and you'll all be safer here than in any city. There's Darkfriends in cities."

"lɪsən," pɛɹɪn sɛɾ ɝdʒənli, "aɪ wɪʃ jud stɑp seɪɪŋ ðæt. aɪ kænt - də ðət . . . wʌt jə du, wʌt jəɹ seɪɪŋ."

"Listen," Perrin said urgently, "I wish you'd stop saying that. I can't - do that . . . what you do, what you're saying."

"æz jə wɪʃ, bɔɪ. pleɪ ðə ɡoʊt, ɪf juv ə maɪn tə. doʊn jə wɑnə bi seɪf?"

"As you wish, boy. Play the goat, if you've a mind to. Don't you want to be safe?"

"aɪm nɑt dɪsivɪŋ maɪsɛlf. ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ tə dɪsiv maɪsɛlf əbaʊt. ɔl wi wɑnt - "

"I'm not deceiving myself. There's nothing to deceive myself about. All we want - "

"wi ɑɹ ɡoʊɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn," ɛɡwin spoʊk ʌp fɝmli. "æn ðən tə tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"We are going to Caemlyn," Egwene spoke up firmly. "And then to Tar Valon."

kloʊzɪŋ ɪz maʊθ, pɛɹɪn mɛɾ əɹ æŋɡɹi lʊk wɪð wʌn ə hɪz oʊn. hi nu ðət ʃi fɑloʊɾ ɪz lɛd wən ʃi wɑntəd tə ən nɑt wən ʃi dɪd nɑt, bʌt ʃi kəɾ ət lis lɛɾ ɪm ænsɝ fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ju, pɛɹɪn?" hi sɛd, ən ænsɝd hɪmsɛlf. "mi? wɛl, lemi θɪŋk. jɛs. jɛs, aɪ θɪŋk əl ɡoʊ ɑn." hi tɝn ə maɪl smaɪl ɑn hɝ. "wɛl, ɛɡwin, ðət meɪks boʊθ ʌv ʌs. aɪ ɡɛs aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ wɪð ju, ət ðæt. ɡʊd tə tɔk ðiz θɪŋz aʊt bɪfɔɹ meɪkɪŋ ə dɪsɪʒən, ɪzən ɪt?" ʃi blʌʃt, bʌt ðə sɛɾ ə hɝ dʒɔ nɛvɝ lɛsənd.

Closing his mouth, Perrin met her angry look with one of his own. He knew that she followed his lead when she wanted to and not when she did not, but she could at least let him answer for himself. "What about you, Perrin?" he said, and answered himself. "Me? Well, let me think. Yes. Yes, I think I'll go on." He turned a mild smile on her. "Well, Egwene, that makes both of us. I guess I'm going with you, at that. Good to talk these things out before making a decision, isn't it?" She blushed, but the set of her jaw never lessened.

ɛlaɪəs ɡɹʌntɪd. "dæpəl sɛd ðæts wʌt jud dɪsaɪd. ʃi sɛd ðə ɡɝlz plæntəd fɝmli ɪn ðə hjumən wɝld, waɪl ju" - hi nɑɾəd ət pɛɹɪn -  "stæn hæfweɪ bɪtwin. ʌndɝ ðə sɝkəmstænsəz, aɪ səpoʊz wid bɛɾɝ ɡoʊ saʊθ wɪð ju. ʌðɝwaɪz, jəl pɹɑbli stɑɹv tə dɛθ, əɹ ɡɛt lɔst, əɹ - "

Elyas grunted. "Dapple said that's what you'd decide. She said the girl's planted firmly in the human world, while you" - he nodded at Perrin -  "stand halfway between. Under the circumstances, I suppose we'd better go south with you. Otherwise, you'll probably starve to death, or get lost, or - "

əbɹʌpli bɝn stʊɾ ʌp, ən ɛlaɪəs tɝn ɪz hɛd tə ɹəɡɑɹd ðə bɪɡ wʊlf. æftɝ ə moʊmən dæpəl ɹoʊz, tu. ʃi muv kloʊsɝ tə ɛlaɪəs, soʊ ðət ʃi ɔlsoʊ wɑz miɾɪŋ bɝnz stɛɹ. ðə təbloʊ wɑz fɹoʊzən fəɹ lɔŋ mɪnəts, ðən bɝn wɝld ən vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə naɪt. dæpəl ʃʊk hɝsɛlf, ðən ɹɪzumd əɹ pleɪs, flɑpɪŋ daʊn əz ɪf nʌθɪŋ hæd hæpənd.

Abruptly Burn stood up, and Elyas turned his head to regard the big wolf. After a moment Dapple rose, too. She moved closer to Elyas, so that she also was meeting Burn's stare. The tableau was frozen for long minutes, then Burn whirled and vanished into the night. Dapple shook herself, then resumed her place, flopping down as if nothing had happened.

ɛlaɪəs mɛt pɛɹɪnz kwɛstʃənɪŋ aɪz. "dæpəl ɹʌnz ðɪs pæk," hi ɪkspleɪnd. "sʌm ə ðə meɪlz kəd bɛst əɹ ɪf ðeɪ tʃælənʒd, bʌt ʃiz smɑɹɾɝ ðən ɛni ʌv ðɛm, ən ðeɪ ɔl noʊ ɪt. ʃiz seɪv ðə pæk mɔɹ ðən wʌns. bʌt bɝn θɪŋks ðə pæk ɪz weɪstɪŋ taɪm wɪð jə θɹi. heɪɾɪŋ tʃɹɑləks ɪz əbaʊɾ ɔl ðəɹ ɪz tə hɪm, ən ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ tʃɹɑləks ðɪs fɑɹ saʊθ i wɑns tə bi ɔf kɪlɪŋ ðɛm."

Elyas met Perrin's questioning eyes. "Dapple runs this pack," he explained. "Some of the males could best her if they challenged, but she's smarter than any of them, and they all know it. She's saved the pack more than once. But Burn thinks the pack is wasting time with you three. Hating Trollocs is about all there is to him, and if there are Trollocs this far south he wants to be off killing them."

"wi kwaɪɾ ʌndɝstænd," ɛɡwin sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ɹɪlivd. "wi ɹɪli kən faɪn əɹ oʊn weɪ . . . wɪð səm dɝɛkʃənz, ʌv kɔɹs, ɪf jəl ɡɪv ðɛm."

"We quite understand," Egwene said, sounding relieved. "We really can find our own way . . . with some directions, of course, if you'll give them."

ɛlaɪəs weɪvd ə hænd. "aɪ sɛd dæpəl lidz ðɪs pæk, dɪdn aɪ? ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, əl stɑɹt saʊθ wɪð ju, ən soʊ wɪl ðeɪ." ɛɡwin lʊkt əz ɪf ðət wɑz nɑt ðə bɛs nuz ʃi kəɾ əv hɝd.

Elyas waved a hand. "I said Dapple leads this pack, didn't I? In the morning, I'll start south with you, and so will they." Egwene looked as if that was not the best news she could have heard.

pɛɹɪn sæt ɹæpt ɪn ɪz oʊn saɪləns. hi kəd fil bɝn livɪŋ. ən ðə skɑɹd meɪl wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn; ə dʌzən ʌðɝz, ɔl jʌŋ meɪlz, loʊpt æftɝ hɪm. hi wɑntəd tə bɪliv ɪt wɑz ɔl ɛlaɪəs pleɪɪŋ ɑn ɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt. dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ ðə dɪpɑɹɾɪŋ wʊlvz feɪɾəd fɹəm ɪz maɪnd, hi fɛlt ə θɔɾ i nu keɪm fɹəm bɝn, əz ʃɑɹp ən klɪɹ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ɪz oʊn θɔt. heɪtʃɹəd. heɪtʃɹəɾ ən ðə teɪst ə blʌd.

Perrin sat wrapped in his own silence. He could feel Burn leaving. And the scarred male was not the only one; a dozen others, all young males, loped after him. He wanted to believe it was all Elyas playing on his imagination, but he could not. Just before the departing wolves faded from his mind, he felt a thought he knew came from Burn, as sharp and clear as if it were his own thought. Hatred. Hatred and the taste of blood.


tʃæptɝ twɛntifɔɹ


CHAPTER 24

flaɪt daʊn ði ɑɹɪnɛl


Flight Down the Arinelle

wɔɾɝ dʒɹɪpt ɪn ðə dɪstəns, hɑloʊ splæʃəz ɛkoʊɪŋ ən ɹitʃoʊɪŋ, luzɪŋ ðɛɹ sɔɹs fɝɛvɝ. ðəɹ wɝ stoʊn bɹɪdʒəz ən ɹeɪləs ɹæmps ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ɔl spɹaʊɾɪŋ ɔf fɹəm bɹɔd, flæt-tɑp stoʊn spaɪɹz, ɔl pɑlɪʃt ən smuð ən stʃɹikt wɪð ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld. lɛvəl ɑn lɛvəl, ðə meɪz stʃɹɛtʃt ʌp ən daʊn θɹu ðə mɝk, wɪθaʊɾ ɛni əpɛɹən bɪɡɪnɪŋ əɹ ɛnd. ɛvɹi bɹɪdʒ lɛd tə ə spaɪɹ, ɛvɹi ɹæmp tə ənʌðɝ spaɪɹ, ʌðɝ bɹɪdʒəz. wʌtɛvɝ dɝɛkʃən ɹænd lʊkt, əz fɑɹ əz ɪz aɪ kəd meɪk aʊɾ ɪn ðə dɪmnəs ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm, əbʌv əz wɛl əz bɪloʊ. ðəɹ wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf laɪt tə si klɪɹli, ən i wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɡlæɾ ʌv ɪt. səm ə ðoʊz ɹæmps lɛd tə plætfɔɹmz ðət hæd tə bi dɝɛkli əbʌv ðə wʌnz bɪloʊ. hi kəd nɑt si ðə beɪs ʌv ɛni ʌv ðɛm. hi pɹɛst, sikɪŋ fɹiɾəm, noʊɪŋ ɪt wɑz ən ɪluʒən. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz ɪluʒən.

Water dripped in the distance, hollow splashes echoing and reechoing, losing their source forever. There were stone bridges and railless ramps everywhere, all sprouting off from broad, flat-topped stone spires, all polished and smooth and streaked with red and gold. Level on level, the maze stretched up and down through the murk, without any apparent beginning or end. Every bridge led to a spire, every ramp to another spire, other bridges. Whatever direction Rand looked, as far as his eye could make out in the dimness it was the same, above as well as below. There was not enough light to see clearly, and he was almost glad of it. Some of those ramps led to platforms that had to be directly above the ones below. He could not see the base of any of them. He pressed, seeking freedom, knowing it was an illusion. Everything was illusion.

hi nu ði ɪluʒən; hi hæd fɑloʊɾ ɪt tu mɛni taɪmz nɑt tə noʊ. haʊɛvɝ fɑɹ i wɛnt, ʌp əɹ daʊn əɹ ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən, ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə ʃaɪni stoʊn. stoʊn, bʌt ðə dæŋknəs ə dip, fɹɛʃ-tɝn ɝθ pɝmieɪɾɪd ði ɛɹ, ən ðə sɪkli switnəs ə dəkeɪ. ðə smɛl ʌv ə ɡɹeɪv oʊpən aʊɾ ʌv ɪts taɪm. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə bɹið, bʌt ðə smɛl fɪld ɪz nɑstʃɹəlz. ɪt klʌŋ tə hɪz skɪn laɪk ɔɪl.

He knew the illusion; he had followed it too many times not to know. However far he went, up or down or in any direction, there was only the shiny stone. Stone, but the dankness of deep, fresh-turned earth permeated the air, and the sickly sweetness of decay. The smell of a grave opened out of its time. He tried not to breathe, but the smell filled his nostrils. It clung to his skin like oil.

ə flɪkɝ ə moʊʃən kɑɾ ɪz aɪ, ən i fɹoʊz wɛɹ i wɑz, hæf kɹaʊtʃt əɡɛns ðə pɑlɪʃt ɡɑɹdwəl ɝaʊnd wʌn ə ðə spaɪɹ tɑps. ɪt wɑz noʊ haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs. fɹəm ə θaʊzən pleɪsəz ə wɑtʃɝ cʊɾə sin hɪm. ʃædoʊ fɪl ði ɛɹ, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ noʊ dipɝ ʃædoʊz ɪn wɪtʃ tə haɪd. ðə laɪt dɪd nɑt kʌm fɹəm læmps, əɹ læntɝnz, əɹ tɔɹtʃɪz; ɪt wɑz sɪmpli ðɛɹ, sətʃ əz ɪt wɑz, əz ɪf ɪt sipt aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ. ɪnʌf baɪ wɪtʃ tə si, æftɝ ə fæʃən; ɪnʌf baɪ wɪtʃ tə bi sin. bʌt stɪlnəs ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl pɹətɛkʃən.

A flicker of motion caught his eye, and he froze where he was, half crouched against the polished guardwall around one of the spire tops. It was no hiding place. From a thousand places a watcher could have seen him. Shadow filled the air, but there were no deeper shadows in which to hide. The light did not come from lamps, or lanterns, or torches; it was simply there, such as it was, as if it seeped out of the air. Enough by which to see, after a fashion; enough by which to be seen. But stillness gave a little protection.

ðə muvmən keɪm əɡɛn, ən naʊ ɪt wɑz klɪɹ. ə mæn stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp ə dɪstən ɹæmp, kɛɹləs ə ðə læk ə ɹeɪlɪŋz ən ðə dʒɹɑp tə nʌθɪŋ bɪloʊ. ðə mænz kloʊk ɹɪpəld wɪð ɪz steɪtli heɪst, ən ɪz hɛd tɝnd, sɝtʃɪŋ, sɝtʃɪŋ. ðə dɪstəns wɑz tu fɑɹ fəɹ ɹænd tə si mɔɹ ðən ðə ʃeɪp ɪn ðə mɝk, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt nid tə bi kloʊsɝ tə noʊ ðə kloʊk wɑz ðə ɹɛɾ ə fɹɛʃ blʌd, ðət ðə sɝtʃɪŋ aɪz bleɪz laɪk tu fɝnəsəz.

The movement came again, and now it was clear. A man striding up a distant ramp, careless of the lack of railings and the drop to nothing below. The man's cloak rippled with his stately haste, and his head turned, searching, searching. The distance was too far for Rand to see more than the shape in the murk, but he did not need to be closer to know the cloak was the red of fresh blood, that the searching eyes blazed like two furnaces.

hi tʃɹaɪd tʃɹeɪsɪŋ ðə meɪz wɪð ɪz aɪz, tə si haʊ mɛni kənɛkʃənz bælzəmən niɾəd bɪfɔɹ ɹitʃɪŋ hɪm, ðən ɡeɪv ɪɾ ʌp əz jusləs. dɪstənsəz wɝ dɪsivɪŋ hɪɹ, ənʌðɝ lɛsən i hæd lɝnd. wʌt sim fɑɹ əweɪ maɪt bi ɹitʃt baɪ tɝnɪŋ ə kɔɹnɝ; wʌɾ əpɪɹd kloʊs kəd bi aʊɾ ə ɹitʃ ɔltəɡɛðɝ. ði oʊnli θɪŋ tə du, əz ɪt hæd bɪn fɹəm ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, wɑz tə kip muvɪŋ. kip muvɪŋ, ən nɑt θɪŋk. θɪŋkɪŋ wɑz deɪnʒɝəs, hi nu.

He tried tracing the maze with his eyes, to see how many connections Ba'alzamon needed before reaching him, then gave it up as useless. Distances were deceiving here, another lesson he had learned. What seemed far away might be reached by turning a corner; what appeared close could be out of reach altogether. The only thing to do, as it had been from the beginning, was to keep moving. Keep moving, and not think. Thinking was dangerous, he knew.

jɛt, əz i tɝn əweɪ fɹəm bælzəmənz dɪstən fɔɹm, hi kəd nɑt hɛlp wʌndɝɪŋ əbaʊt mæt. wɑz mæt sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðɪs meɪz? əɹ ɑɹ ðəɹ tu meɪzɪz, tu bælzəmənz? hɪz maɪn skɪɾɝd əweɪ fɹəm ðæt; ɪt wɑz tu dʒɹɛdfəl tə dwɛl ɑn. ɪz ðɪs laɪk bɛɹlən? ðən waɪ kæn i faɪn mi? ðət wɑz ə lɪɾəl bɛɾɝ. ə smɔl kʌmfɝt. kʌmfɝt? blʌɾ ən æʃəz, wɛɹz ðə kʌmfɝɾ ɪn ɪt?

Yet, as he turned away from Ba'alzamon's distant form, he could not help wondering about Mat. Was Mat somewhere in this maze? Or are there two mazes, two Ba'alzamons? His mind skittered away from that; it was too dreadful to dwell on. Is this like Baerlon? Then why can't he find me? That was a little better. A small comfort. Comfort? Blood and ashes, where's the comfort in it?

ðəɹ hæd bɪn tu əɹ θɹi kloʊs bɹʌʃɪz, ðoʊ hi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ əm klɪɹli, bʌt fəɹ ə lɔŋ, lɔŋ taɪm - haʊ lɔŋ? - hi hæd ɹʌn waɪl bælzəmən veɪnli pɝsud. wɑz ðɪs laɪk bɛɹlən, əɹ wɑz ɪɾ oʊnli ə naɪtmɛɹ, oʊnli ə dʒɹim laɪk ʌðɝ mɛnz dʒɹimz?

There had been two or three close brushes, though he could not remember them clearly, but for a long, long time - how long? - he had run while Ba'alzamon vainly pursued. Was this like Baerlon, or was it only a nightmare, only a dream like other men's dreams?

fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ðən - dʒʌs fəɹ ðə lɛŋθ ə taɪm ɪt tʊk tə teɪk ə bɹɛθ - hi nu waɪ ɪt wɑz deɪnʒɝəs tə θɪŋk, wʌɾ ɪt wɑz deɪnʒɝəs tə θɪŋk əbaʊt. əz ɪt hæd bɪfɔɹ, ɛvɹi taɪm i əlaʊd hɪmsɛlf tə θɪŋk ʌv wʌt sɝaʊndəɾ ɪm əz ə dʒɹim, ði ɛɹ ʃɪmɝd, klaʊɾɪŋ ɪz aɪz. ɪt tɝn tə dʒɛl, hoʊldɪŋ hɪm. dʒʌs fəɹ ən ɪnstənt.

For an instant, then - just for the length of time it took to take a breath - he knew why it was dangerous to think, what it was dangerous to think about. As it had before, every time he allowed himself to think of what surrounded him as a dream, the air shimmered, clouding his eyes. It turned to jell, holding him. Just for an instant.

ðə ɡɹɪɾi hit pɹɪkəld ɪz skɪn, ən ɪz θɹoʊt hæd lɔŋ sɪns ɡɔn dʒɹaɪ əz i tʃɹɑɾəd daʊn ðə θɔɹn-hɛdʒ meɪz. haʊ lɔŋ hæɾ ɪt bɪn naʊ? hɪz swɛɾ ɪvæpɝeɪɾəd bɪfɔɹ ɪt hæɾ ə tʃæns tə bid, ən ɪz aɪz bɝnd. oʊvɝhɛd - ən nɑt tu fɑɹ oʊvɝhɛd, ət ðət - bɔɪl fjʊɹiəs, stili klaʊdz stʃɹikt wɪð blæk, bʌt nɑɾ ə bɹɛθ ʌv ɛɹ stɝɾ ɪn ðə meɪz. fəɹ ə moʊmən i θɔɾ ɪt hæd bɪn dɪfɹənt, bʌt ðə θɔɾ ɪvæpɝeɪɾəd ɪn ðə hit. hi hæd bɪn hɪɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm. ɪt wɑz deɪnʒɝəs tə θɪŋk, hi nu ðæt.

The gritty heat prickled his skin, and his throat had long since gone dry as he trotted down the thorn-hedge maze. How long had it been now? His sweat evaporated before it had a chance to bead, and his eyes burned. Overhead - and not too far overhead, at that - boiled furious, steely clouds streaked with black, but not a breath of air stirred in the maze. For a moment he thought it had been different, but the thought evaporated in the heat. He had been here a long time. It was dangerous to think, he knew that.

smuð stoʊnz, peɪl ən ɹaʊndəd, meɪɾ ə skɛtʃi peɪvmənt, hæf bɛɹiɾ ɪn ðə boʊn-dʒɹaɪ dʌs ðət ɹoʊz ɪn pʌfs əɾ ivən ɪz laɪɾəst stɛp. ɪt tɪkəld ɪz noʊz, θɹɛɾənɪŋ ə sniz ðət maɪt ɡɪv ɪm əweɪ; wən i tʃɹaɪd tə bɹið θɹu hɪz maʊθ, dʌs klɔɡd ɪz θɹoʊɾ əntɪl i tʃoʊkt.

Smooth stones, pale and rounded, made a sketchy pavement, half buried in the bone-dry dust that rose in puffs at even his lightest step. It tickled his nose, threatening a sneeze that might give him away; when he tried to breathe through his mouth, dust clogged his throat until he choked.

ðɪs wɑz ə deɪnʒɝəs pleɪs; hi nu ðæt, tu. əhɛɾ ə hɪm i kəd si θɹi oʊpənɪŋz ɪn ðə haɪ wɔl ə θɔɹnz, ðən ðə weɪ kɝvd aʊɾ ə saɪt. bælzəmən kəd bi əpɹoʊtʃɪŋ ɛni wʌn ə ðoʊz kɔɹnɝz ət ðət vɛɹi moʊmənt. ðəɹ hæd bɪn tu əɹ θɹi ɪnkaʊntɝz ɔlɹɛɾi, ðoʊ hi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ mʌtʃ bɪɑn ðət ðeɪ hæd hæpən ən i hæɾ ɪskeɪpt . . . sʌmhaʊ. deɪnʒɝəs tə θɪŋk tu mʌtʃ.

This was a dangerous place; he knew that, too. Ahead of him he could see three openings in the high wall of thorns, then the way curved out of sight. Ba'alzamon could be approaching any one of those corners at that very moment. There had been two or three encounters already, though he could not remember much beyond that they had happened and he had escaped . . . somehow. Dangerous to think too much.

pæntɪŋ ɪn ðə hit, hi stɑp tə ɪɡzæmɪn ðə meɪz wɔl. θɪkli woʊvən θɔɹn bʊʃəz, bɹaʊn ən dɛd-lʊkɪŋ, wɪð kɹuəl blæk θɔɹnz laɪk ɪntʃ-lɔŋ hʊks. tu tɔl tə si oʊvɝ, tu dɛns tə si θɹu. dʒɪnʒɝli hi tʌtʃt ðə wɔl, ən ɡæspt. dɪspaɪɾ ɔl ɪz kɛɹ, ə θɔɹn pɪɹst ɪz fɪŋɡɝ, bɝnɪŋ laɪk ə hɑt niɾəl. hi stʌmbəl bæk, hɪz hilz kætʃɪŋ ɑn ðə stoʊnz, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hæn ən skæɾɝɪŋ θɪk dʒɹɑps ə blʌd. ðə bɝn bɪɡæn tə səbsaɪd, bʌɾ ɪz hoʊl hæn θɹɑbd.

Panting in the heat, he stopped to examine the maze wall. Thickly woven thorn bushes, brown and dead-looking, with cruel black thorns like inch-long hooks. Too tall to see over, too dense to see through. Gingerly he touched the wall, and gasped. Despite all his care, a thorn pierced his finger, burning like a hot needle. He stumbled back, his heels catching on the stones, shaking his hand and scattering thick drops of blood. The burn began to subside, but his whole hand throbbed.

əbɹʌpli hi fɝɡɑt ðə peɪn. hɪz hil hæɾ oʊvɝtɝnd wʌn ə ðə smuð stoʊnz, kɪkt ɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə dʒɹaɪ ɡɹaʊnd. hi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪt, ən ɛmpti aɪ sɑkəts stɛɹd bæk. ə skʌl. ə hjumən skʌl. hi lʊkt əlɔŋ ðə pæθweɪ əɾ ɔl ðə smuð, peɪl stoʊnz, ɔl ɪɡzækli əlaɪk. hi ʃɪftəɾ ɪz fit heɪstəli, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt muv wɪθaʊt wɔkɪŋ ɑn ðɛm, ən i kəd nɑt steɪ stɪl wɪθaʊt stændɪŋ ɑn ðɛm. ə stʃɹeɪ θɔt tʊk veɪɡ ʃeɪp, ðət θɪŋz maɪt nɑt bi wʌt ðeɪ simd, bʌɾ i pʊʃt ɪt daʊn ɹuθləsli. θɪŋkɪŋ wɑz deɪnʒɝəs hɪɹ.

Abruptly he forgot the pain. His heel had overturned one of the smooth stones, kicked it out of the dry ground. He stared at it, and empty eye sockets stared back. A skull. A human skull. He looked along the pathway at all the smooth, pale stones, all exactly alike. He shifted his feet hastily, but he could not move without walking on them, and he could not stay still without standing on them. A stray thought took vague shape, that things might not be what they seemed, but he pushed it down ruthlessly. Thinking was dangerous here.

hi tʊk ə ʃeɪki hoʊld ɑn hɪmsɛlf. steɪɪŋ ɪn wʌn pleɪs wɑz deɪnʒɝəs, tu. ðət wɑz wʌn ə ðə θɪŋz i nu dɪmli bʌt wɪð sɝɾənti. ðə floʊ ʌv blʌd fɹəm ɪz fɪŋɡɝ hæd dwɪndəl tə ə sloʊ dʒɹɪp, ən ðə θɹəb wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɡɔn. sʌkɪŋ ɪz fɪŋɡɝɾɪp, hi stɑɹɾəd daʊn ðə pæθ ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən i hæpən tə bi feɪsɪŋ. wʌn weɪ wɑz əz ɡʊɾ əz ənʌðɝ ɪn hɪɹ.

He took a shaky hold on himself. Staying in one place was dangerous, too. That was one of the things he knew dimly but with certainty. The flow of blood from his finger had dwindled to a slow drip, and the throb was almost gone. Sucking his fingertip, he started down the path in the direction he happened to be facing. One way was as good as another in here.

naʊ hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd hɪɹɪŋ wʌns ðət jə kəd ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ʌv ə meɪz baɪ ɔlweɪz tɝnɪŋ ɪn ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən. ət ðə fɝst oʊpənɪŋ ɪn ðə wɔl ə θɔɹnz i tɝn ɹaɪt, ðən ɹaɪɾ əɡɛn ət ðə nɛkst. ən faʊn hɪmsɛlf feɪs-tə-feɪs wɪð bælzəmən.

Now he remembered hearing once that you could get out of a maze by always turning in the same direction. At the first opening in the wall of thorns he turned right, then right again at the next. And found himself face-to-face with Ba'alzamon.

sɝpɹaɪz flɪɾɪd əkɹɔs bælzəmənz feɪs, ən ɪz blʌd-ɹɛd kloʊk sɛɾəld əz i stɑpt ʃɔɹt. fleɪmz sɔɹɾ ɪn ɪz aɪz, bʌɾ ɪn ðə hiɾ ə ðə meɪz ɹænd bɛɹli fɛl ðɛm.

Surprise flitted across Ba'alzamon's face, and his blood-red cloak settled as he stopped short. Flames soared in his eyes, but in the heat of the maze Rand barely felt them.

"haʊ lɔŋ dʒju θɪŋk jə kən ɪveɪd mi, bɔɪ? haʊ lɔŋ dʒju θɪŋk jə kən ɪveɪd jəɹ feɪt? jə ɑɹ maɪn!"

"How long do you think you can evade me, boy? How long do you think you can evade your fate? You are mine!"

stʌmbəlɪŋ bæk, ɹænd wʌndɝd waɪ hi wɑz fʌmbəlɪŋ əɾ ɪz bɛlt, əz ɪf fəɹ ə sɔɹd. "laɪt hɛlp mi," hi mʌɾɝd. "laɪt hɛlp mi." hi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ ɪt mɛnt.

Stumbling back, Rand wondered why he was fumbling at his belt, as if for a sword. "Light help me," he muttered. "Light help me." He could not remember what it meant.

"ðə laɪt wɪl nɑt hɛlp ju, bɔɪ, ən ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld wɪl nɑt sɝv ju. jə ɑɹ maɪ haʊnd, ən ɪf jəl nɑt kɔɹs ət maɪ kəmænd, əl stʃɹæŋɡəl jə wɪð ðə kɔɹps ə ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpənt!"

"The Light will not help you, boy, and the Eye of the World will not serve you. You are my hound, and if you will not course at my command, I will strangle you with the corpse of the Great Serpent!"

bælzəmən stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ɪz hænd, ən sʌɾənli ɹænd nu ə weɪ tə ɪskeɪp, ə mɪsti, hæf-fɔɹmd mɛmɹi ðət skɹim deɪnʒɝ, bʌt nʌθɪŋ tə ðə deɪnʒɝ ə biɪŋ tʌtʃt baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn.

Ba'alzamon stretched out his hand, and suddenly Rand knew a way to escape, a misty, half-formed memory that screamed danger, but nothing to the danger of being touched by the Dark One.

"ə dʒɹim!" ɹænd ʃaʊɾəd. "ðɪs ɪz ə dʒɹim!"

"A dream!" Rand shouted. "This is a dream!"

bælzəmənz aɪz bɪɡæn tə waɪɾən, ɪn sɝpɹaɪz əɹ æŋɡɝ əɹ boʊθ, ðən ði ɛɹ ʃɪmɝd, ən ɪz fitʃɝz blɝd, ən feɪɾəd.

Ba'alzamon's eyes began to widen, in surprise or anger or both, then the air shimmered, and his features blurred, and faded.

ɹænd tɝn əbaʊɾ ɪn wʌn spɑt, stɛɹɪŋ. stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪz oʊn ɪmədʒ θɹoʊn bæk əɾ ɪm ə θaʊzændfoʊld. tɛn θaʊzændfoʊld. əbʌv wɑz blæknəs, ən blæknəs bɪloʊ, bʌɾ ɔl ɝaʊn ɪm stʊd mɪɹɝz, mɪɹɝz sɛɾ əɾ ɛvɹi æŋɡəl, mɪɹɝz əz fɑɹ əz i kəd si, ɔl ʃoʊɪŋ hɪm, kɹaʊtʃt ən tɝnɪŋ, stɛɹɪŋ waɪd-aɪɾ ən fɹaɪɾənd.

Rand turned about in one spot, staring. Staring at his own image thrown back at him a thousandfold. Ten thousandfold. Above was blackness, and blackness below, but all around him stood mirrors, mirrors set at every angle, mirrors as far as he could see, all showing him, crouched and turning, staring wide-eyed and frightened.

ə ɹɛd blɝ dʒɹɪftəɾ əkɹɔs ðə mɪɹɝz. hi spʌn, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kætʃ ɪt, bʌɾ ɪn ɛvɹi mɪɹɝ ɪt dʒɹɪftəd bɪhaɪn ɪz oʊn ɪmədʒ ən vænɪʃt. ðən ɪt wɑz bæk əɡɛn, bʌt nɑɾ əz ə blɝ. bælzəmən stʃɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə mɪɹɝz, tɛn θaʊzən bælzəmənz, sɝtʃɪŋ, kɹɔsɪŋ ən ɹɛkɹɔsɪŋ ðə sɪlvɝi mɪɹɝz.

A red blur drifted across the mirrors. He spun, trying to catch it, but in every mirror it drifted behind his own image and vanished. Then it was back again, but not as a blur. Ba'alzamon strode across the mirrors, ten thousand Ba'alzamons, searching, crossing and recrossing the silvery mirrors.

hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ɹəflɛkʃən ə hɪz oʊn feɪs, peɪl ən ʃɪvɝɪŋ ɪn ðə naɪf-ɛdʒ koʊld. bælzəmənz ɪmədʒ ɡɹu bɪhaɪn hɪz, stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm; nɑt siɪŋ, bʌt stɛɹɪŋ stɪl. ɪn ɛvɹi mɪɹɝ, ðə fleɪmz ə bælzəmənz feɪs ɹeɪdʒ bɪhaɪn hɪm, ɪnvɛləpɪŋ, kənsumɪŋ, mɝdʒɪŋ. hi wɑntəd tə skɹim, bʌɾ ɪz θɹoʊt wɑz fɹoʊzən. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn feɪs ɪn ðoʊz ɛnləs mɪɹɝz. hɪz oʊn feɪs. bælzəmənz feɪs. wʌn feɪs.

He found himself staring at the reflection of his own face, pale and shivering in the knife-edge cold. Ba'alzamon's image grew behind his, staring at him; not seeing, but staring still. In every mirror, the flames of Ba'alzamon's face raged behind him, enveloping, consuming, merging. He wanted to scream, but his throat was frozen. There was only one face in those endless mirrors. His own face. Ba'alzamon's face. One face.

ɹænd dʒɝkt, ən oʊpən ɪz aɪz. dɑɹknəs, lɛsən oʊnli slaɪtli baɪ ə peɪl laɪt. bɛɹli bɹiðɪŋ, hi muv nʌθɪŋ ɪksɛpt ɪz aɪz. ə ɹʌf wʊl blæŋkət kʌvɝɾ ɪm tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz, ən ɪz hɛd wɑz kɹæɾəld ɑn ɪz ɑɹmz. hi kəd fil smuð wʊɾən plæŋks ʌndɝ ɪz hænz. dɛk plæŋks. ɹɪɡɪŋ kɹikt ɪn ðə naɪt. hi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ. hi wɑz ɑn ðə spɹeɪ. ɪt wɑz oʊvɝ . . . fəɹ ənʌðɝ naɪt, ət list.

Rand jerked, and opened his eyes. Darkness, lessened only slightly by a pale light. Barely breathing, he moved nothing except his eyes. A rough wool blanket covered him to his shoulders, and his head was cradled on his arms. He could feel smooth wooden planks under his hands. Deck planks. Rigging creaked in the night. He let out a long breath. He was on the Spray. It was over . . . for another night, at least.

wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ i pʊɾ ɪz fɪŋɡɝ ɪn ɪz maʊθ. ət ðə teɪst ə blʌd, hi stɑp bɹiðɪŋ. sloʊli hi pʊɾ ɪz hæn kloʊs tə hɪz feɪs, tə wɛɹ i kəd si ɪn ðə dɪm munlaɪt, tə wɛɹ i kəd wɑtʃ ðə biɾ ə blʌd fɔɹm ɑn ɪz fɪŋɡɝɾɪp. blʌd fɹəm ðə pɹɪk ʌv ə θɔɹn.

Without thinking he put his finger in his mouth. At the taste of blood, he stopped breathing. Slowly he put his hand close to his face, to where he could see in the dim moonlight, to where he could watch the bead of blood form on his fingertip. Blood from the prick of a thorn.

ðə spɹeɪ meɪd heɪst sloʊli daʊn ði ɑɹɪnɛl. ðə wɪn keɪm stʃɹɔŋ, bʌt fɹəm dɝɛkʃənz ðət meɪd ðə seɪlz jusləs. wɪð ɔl kæptən doʊmənz dɪmæn fəɹ spid, ðə vɛsəl kɹɛpt əlɔŋ. baɪ naɪɾ ə mæn ɪn ðə baʊz kæst ə tæloʊd lɛd baɪ læntɝn laɪt, kɔlɪŋ bæk ðə dɛpθ tə ðə stɪɹsmən, waɪl ðə kɝən kæɹiɾ əɹ daʊnɹɪvɝ əɡɛns ðə wɪnd wɪð ðə swips pʊld ɪn. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɹɑks tə fɪɹ ɪn ði ɑɹɪnɛl, bʌt ʃæloʊz ən ʃoʊlz ðəɹ wɝ əplɛnti, wɛɹ ə boʊt kəd ɡoʊ hɑɹɾ əɡɹaʊn tə ɹɪmeɪn, baʊz ən mɔɹ dʌɡ ɪndə ðə mʌd, əntɪl hɛlp keɪm. ɪf ɪt wɑz hɛlp ðət keɪm fɝst. baɪ deɪ ðə swips wɝk fɹəm sʌnɹaɪz tə sʌnsɛt, bʌt ðə wɪn fɔɾ əm əz ɪf ɪt wɑntəd tə pʊʃ ðə boʊt bæk ʌpɹɪvɝ.

The Spray made haste slowly down the Arinelle. The wind came strong, but from directions that made the sails useless. With all Captain Domon's demand for speed, the vessel crept along. By night a man in the bows cast a tallowed lead by lantern light, calling back the depth to the steersman, while the current carried her downriver against the wind with the sweeps pulled in. There were no rocks to fear in the Arinelle, but shallows and shoals there were aplenty, where a boat could go hard aground to remain, bows and more dug into the mud, until help came. If it was help that came first. By day the sweeps worked from sunrise to sunset, but the wind fought them as if it wanted to push the boat back upriver.

ðeɪ dɪd nɑt pʊɾ ɪn tə ʃɔɹ, niðɝ baɪ deɪ nɔɹ baɪ naɪt. beɪl doʊmən dʒɹoʊv boʊɾ ən kɹu əlaɪk hɑɹd, ɹeɪlɪŋ ət ðə kɑntʃɹɛɹi wɪnz, kɝsɪŋ ðə sloʊ peɪs. hi blɪstɝd ðə kɹu fəɹ slʌɡɑɝdz ət ði ɔɹz ən fleɪɾ əm wɪð ɪz tʌŋ fəɹ ɛvɹi mɪshændəld laɪn, hɪz loʊ, hɑɹd vɔɪs peɪntɪŋ tʃɹɑləks tɛn fit tɔl əmʌŋ əm ɑn ðə dɛk, ɹɪpɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ θɹoʊts. fəɹ tu deɪz ðət wɑz ɪnʌf tə sɛn ɛvɹi mæn lipɪŋ. ðən ðə ʃɑk ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ətæk bɪɡæn tə feɪd, ən mɛn bɪɡæn tə mʌɾɝ əbaʊɾ ən aʊɝ tə stʃɹɛtʃ ðɛɹ lɛɡz əʃɔɹ, ən əbaʊt ðə deɪnʒɝz ə ɹʌnɪŋ daʊnɹɪvɝ ɪn ðə dɑɹk.

They did not put in to shore, neither by day nor by night. Bayle Domon drove boat and crew alike hard, railing at the contrary winds, cursing the slow pace. He blistered the crew for sluggards at the oars and flayed them with his tongue for every mishandled line, his low, hard voice painting Trollocs ten feet tall among them on the deck, ripping out their throats. For two days that was enough to send every man leaping. Then the shock of the Trolloc attack began to fade, and men began to mutter about an hour to stretch their legs ashore, and about the dangers of running downriver in the dark.

ðə kɹu kɛp ðɛɹ ɡɹʌmbəlz kwaɪət, wɑtʃɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝz ə ðɛɹ aɪz tə meɪk ʃʊɹ kæptən doʊmən wɑz nɑt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ, bʌɾ i sim tə hɪɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ sɛɾ ɑn ɪz boʊt. itʃ taɪm ðə ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋz bɪɡæn, hi saɪlənli bɹɔɾ aʊt ðə lɔŋ, saɪð-laɪk sɔɹɾ ən kɹuli hʊkt æks ðət hæd bɪn faʊn ɑn ðə dɛk æftɝ ði ətæk. hi wəd hæŋ əm ɑn ðə mæs fəɹ ən aʊɝ, ən ðoʊz u hæd bɪn wundəd wəd fɪŋɡɝ ðɛɹ bændədʒəz, ən ðə mʌɾɝɪŋz kwaɪəɾəd fəɹ ə deɪ əɹ soʊ, ət list, əntɪl wʌn əɹ ənʌðɝ ə ðə kɹu bɪɡæn θɪŋkɪŋ wʌns mɔɹ ðət ʃʊɹli ðeɪ hæd lɛf ðə tʃɹɑləks fɑɹ bɪhaɪn baɪ naʊ, ən ðə saɪkəl bɪɡæn jɛɾ əɡɛn.

The crew kept their grumbles quiet, watching out of the corners of their eyes to make sure Captain Domon was not close enough to hear, but he seemed to hear everything said on his boat. Each time the grumblings began, he silently brought out the long, scythe-like sword and cruelly hooked axe that had been found on the deck after the attack. He would hang them on the mast for an hour, and those who had been wounded would finger their bandages, and the mutterings quieted for a day or so, at least, until one or another of the crew began thinking once more that surely they had left the Trollocs far behind by now, and the cycle began yet again.

ɹænd noʊɾəst ðət tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn steɪd klɪɹ ə ðə kɹu wən ðeɪ bɪɡæn wɪspɝɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ən fɹaʊnɪŋ, ðoʊ juʒəwəli hi wɑz slæpɪŋ bæks ən tɛlɪŋ dʒoʊks ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒɪŋ bæntɝ ɪn ə weɪ ðət pʊɾ ə ɡɹɪn ɑn ivən ðə hɑɹɾəst-wɝkɪŋ mæn. tɑm wɑtʃt ðoʊz sikɹəɾɪv mʌɾɝz wɪð ə wɛɹi aɪ waɪl əpɪɹɪŋ tə bi əbzɔɹbd ɪn laɪɾɪŋ ɪz lɔŋ-stɛm paɪp, əɹ tunɪŋ ɪz hɑɹp, əɹ ɔlmoʊst ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛpt peɪɪŋ ɛni maɪn əɾ ɔl tə ðə kɹu. ɹænd dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə θɹi hu hæd kʌm əbɔɹd tʃeɪs baɪ tʃɹɑləks hum ðə kɹu sim tə bleɪm, bʌt ɹæðɝ flɔɹən dʒɛlb.

Rand noticed that Thom Merrilin stayed clear of the crew when they began whispering together and frowning, though usually he was slapping backs and telling jokes and exchanging banter in a way that put a grin on even the hardest-working man. Thom watched those secretive mutters with a wary eye while appearing to be absorbed in lighting his long-stemmed pipe, or tuning his harp, or almost anything except paying any mind at all to the crew. Rand did not understand why. It was not the three who had come aboard chased by Trollocs whom the crew seemed to blame, but rather Floran Gelb.

fəɹ ðə fɝs deɪ əɹ tu dʒɛlbz wɪɹi fɪɡjɝ kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz bi faʊn ədʒɹɛsɪŋ ɛni kɹumən i kəd kɔɹnɝ, tɛlɪŋ ɪz vɝʒən ə ðə naɪt ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz keɪm ɑn bɔɹd. dʒɛlbz mænɝ slɪd fɹəm blʌstɝ tə waɪnz ən bæk əɡɛn, ən ɪz lɪp ɔlweɪz kɝld wən i pɔɪntəd tə tɑm əɹ mæt, əɹ ɪspɛʃli ɹænd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə leɪ ðə bleɪm ɑn ðɛm.

For the first day or two Gelb's wiry figure could almost always be found addressing any crewman he could corner, telling his version of the night Rand and the others came on board. Gelb's manner slid from bluster to whines and back again, and his lip always curled when he pointed to Thom or Mat, or especially Rand, trying to lay the blame on them.

"ðeɪɹ stʃɹeɪnʒɝz," dʒɛlb pliɾəd, kwaɪətli ən wɪð ən aɪ aʊt fəɹ ðə kæptən. "wʌt də wi noʊ ʌv ðɛm? ðə tʃɹɑləks keɪm wɪð ðɛm, ðæts wʌt wi noʊ. ðəɹ ɪn liɡ."

"They're strangers," Gelb pleaded, quietly and with an eye out for the captain. "What do we know of them? The Trollocs came with them, that's what we know. They're in league."

"fɔɹtʃən, dʒɛlb, stoʊ ɪt," ɡɹaʊld ə mæn wɪð ɪz hɛɹ ɪn ə pɪɡteɪl ən ə smɔl blu stɑɹ tætuɾ ɑn ɪz tʃik. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk ət dʒɛlb əz i kɔɪld ə laɪn ɑn dɛk, wɝkɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn wɪð ɪz bɛɹ toʊz. ɔl ðə seɪlɝz wɛn bɛɹfʊt dɪspaɪt ðə koʊld; buts kəd slɪp ɑn ə wɛt dɛk. "jud kɔl jəɹ mʌðɝ dɑɹkfɹɛn ɪf ɪɾəd lɛt jə slæk. ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm mi!" hi spæɾ ɑn dʒɛlbz fʊɾ ən wɛn bæk tə ðə laɪn.

"Fortune, Gelb, stow it," growled a man with his hair in a pigtail and a small blue star tattooed on his cheek. He did not look at Gelb as he coiled a line on deck, working it in with his bare toes. All the sailors went barefoot despite the cold; boots could slip on a wet deck. "You'd call your mother Darkfriend if it'd let you slack. Get away from me!" He spat on Gelb's foot and went back to the line.

ɔl ðə kɹu ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə wɑtʃ dʒɛlb hæd nɑt kɛpt, ən ðə pɪɡteɪl mænz wɑz ðə pəlaɪɾəst ɹɪspɑns i ɡɑt. noʊ wʌn ivən wɑntəd tə wɝk wɪð hɪm. dʒɛlb faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɹɛləɡeɪɾɪd tə sɑlətɛɹi tæsks, ɔl ə ðɛm fɪlθi, sətʃ əz skɹʌbɪŋ ðə ɡæliz ɡɹisi pɑts, əɹ kɹɔlɪŋ ɪndə ðə bɪlʒz ɑn ɪz bɛli tə sɝtʃ fəɹ liks əmʌŋ jɪɹz ə slaɪm. sun i stɑp tɔkɪŋ tə ɛniwʌn. hɪz ʃoʊldɝz tʊk ɑn ə dɪfɛnsɪv hʌntʃ, ən ɪnʒɝd saɪləns bɪkeɪm ɪz stæns - ðə mɔɹ pipəl wɑtʃɪŋ, ðə mɔɹ ɪnʒɝd, ðoʊ ɪɾ ɝn ɪm noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə ɡɹʌnt. wən dʒɛlbz aɪz fɛl ɑn ɹænd, haʊɛvɝ, əɹ ɑn mæt əɹ tɑm, mɝɾɝ flæʃt əkɹɔs ɪz lɔŋ-noʊz feɪs.

All the crew remembered the watch Gelb had not kept, and the pigtailed man's was the politest response he got. No one even wanted to work with him. Gelb found himself relegated to solitary tasks, all of them filthy, such as scrubbing the galley's greasy pots, or crawling into the bilges on his belly to search for leaks among years of slime. Soon he stopped talking to anyone. His shoulders took on a defensive hunch, and injured silence became his stance - the more people watching, the more injured, though it earned him no more than a grunt. When Gelb's eyes fell on Rand, however, or on Mat or Thom, murder flashed across his long-nosed face.

wən ɹænd mɛnʃən tə mæt ðət dʒɛlb wəd kɑz əm tʃɹʌbəl sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, mæt lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə boʊt, seɪɪŋ, "kæn wi tʃɹʌst ɛni ʌv ðɛm? ɛni əɾ ɔl?" ðən i wɛn ɔf tə faɪn ə pleɪs wɛɹ i kəd bi əloʊn, əɹ əz əloʊn əz i kəd ɡɛɾ ɑn ə boʊt lɛs ðən θɝɾi peɪsɪz fɹəm ɪts ɹeɪz baʊ tə ðə stɝnpoʊst wɛɹ ðə stɪɹɪŋ ɔɹz wɝ maʊntəd. mæt hæd spɛn tu mʌtʃ taɪm əloʊn sɪns ðə naɪɾ ət ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ; bɹuɾɪŋ, əz ɹænd sɔ ɪt.

When Rand mentioned to Mat that Gelb would cause them trouble sooner or later, Mat looked around the boat, saying, "Can we trust any of them? Any at all?" Then he went off to find a place where he could be alone, or as alone as he could get on a boat less than thirty paces from its raised bow to the sternpost where the steering oars were mounted. Mat had spent too much time alone since the night at Shadar Logoth; brooding, as Rand saw it.

tɑm sɛd, "tʃɹʌbəl woʊn kʌm fɹəm dʒɛlb, bɔɪ, ɪf ɪt kʌmz. nɑt jɛt, ət list. nʌn ə ðə kɹu wɪl bæk hɪm, ən i hæzən ðə nɝv tə tʃɹaɪ ɛniθɪŋ əloʊn. bʌt ði ʌðɝz, naʊ . . . ? doʊmən ɔlmoʊst simz tə θɪŋk ðə tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ tʃeɪsɪŋ hɪm, pɝsənəli, bʌt ðə ɹɛst ɑɹ bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə θɪŋk ðə deɪnʒɝ ɪz pæst. ðeɪ maɪt dʒʌs dɪsaɪd ðeɪv hæɾ ɪnʌf. ðəɹ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv ɪt, əz ɪɾ ɪz." hi hɪtʃt ɪz pætʃ-kʌvɝd kloʊk, ən ɹænd hæd ðə filɪŋ i wɑz tʃɛkɪŋ ɪz hɪɾən naɪvz - hɪz sɛkənd-bɛst sɛt. "ɪf ðeɪ mjuɾəni, bɔɪ, ðeɪ woʊn liv pæsənʒɝz bɪhaɪn tə tɛl ðə teɪl. ðə kwinz ɹɪt maɪt nɑɾ əv mʌtʃ fɔɹs ðɪs fɑɹ fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn, bʌɾ ivən ə vɪlədʒ meɪɝ wɪl də sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðæt." ðət wɑz wən ɹænd, tu, bɪɡæn tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə bi noʊɾəst wən i wɑtʃt ðə kɹumɪn.

Thom said, "Trouble won't come from Gelb, boy, if it comes. Not yet, at least. None of the crew will back him, and he hasn't the nerve to try anything alone. But the others, now . . . ? Domon almost seems to think the Trollocs are chasing him, personally, but the rest are beginning to think the danger is past. They might just decide they have had enough. They're on the edge of it, as it is." He hitched his patch-covered cloak, and Rand had the feeling he was checking his hidden knives - his second-best set. "If they mutiny, boy, they won't leave passengers behind to tell the tale. The Queen's Writ might not have much force this far from Caemlyn, but even a village mayor will do something about that." That was when Rand, too, began trying not to be noticed when he watched the crewmen.

tɑm dɪɾ ɪz pɑɹɾ ɪn daɪvɝɾɪŋ ðə kɹu fɹəm θɔts ə mjuɾəni. hi toʊl stɔɹiz, wɪð ɔl ðə flɝɪʃəz, ɛvɹi mɔɹnɪŋ ən ɛvɹi naɪt, ən ɪn bɪtwin i pleɪɾ ɛni sɔŋ ðeɪ ɹɪkwɛstɪd. tə səpɔɹt ðə noʊʃən ðət ɹænd ən mæt wɑntəd tə bi əpɹɛntəs ɡlimən, hi sɛɾ əsaɪɾ ə taɪm itʃ deɪ fəɹ lɛsənz, ən ðət wɑz ən ɛntɝteɪnmən fəɹ ðə kɹu, əz wɛl. hi wəd nɑt lɛɾ iðɝ ə ðɛm tʌtʃ ɪz hɑɹp, ʌv kɔɹs, ən ðɛɹ sɛʃənz wɪð ðə flut pɹədus peɪnd wɪnsəz, ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, ət list, ən læftɝ fɹəm ðə kɹu ivən waɪl ðeɪ wɝ kʌvɝɪŋ ðɛɹ ɪɹz.

Thom did his part in diverting the crew from thoughts of mutiny. He told stories, with all the flourishes, every morning and every night, and in between he played any song they requested. To support the notion that Rand and Mat wanted to be apprentice gleemen, he set aside a time each day for lessons, and that was an entertainment for the crew, as well. He would not let either of them touch his harp, of course, and their sessions with the flute produced pained winces, in the beginning, at least, and laughter from the crew even while they were covering their ears.

hi tɔt ðə bɔɪz səm ə ði iziɝ stɔɹiz, ə lɪɾəl sɪmpəl tʌmbəlɪŋ, ænd, ʌv kɔɹs, dʒʌɡəlɪŋ. mæt kəmpleɪn əbaʊt wʌt tɑm dɪmændəɾ ə ðɛm, bʌt tɑm blu aʊɾ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz ən ɡlɛɹd ɹaɪt bæk.

He taught the boys some of the easier stories, a little simple tumbling, and, of course, juggling. Mat complained about what Thom demanded of them, but Thom blew out his mustaches and glared right back.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ tə pleɪ ət titʃɪŋ, bɔɪ. aɪ iðɝ titʃ ə θɪŋ, əɹ aɪ doʊnt. naʊ! ivən ə kʌntʃɹi bʌmpkɪn ɔt tə bi eɪbəl tə də ə sɪmpəl hændstænd. ʌp jə ɡoʊ."

"I don't know how to play at teaching, boy. I either teach a thing, or I don't. Now! Even a country bumpkin ought to be able to do a simple handstand. Up you go."

kɹumɪn u wɝ nɑt wɝkɪŋ ɔlweɪz ɡæðɝd, skwɑɾɪŋ ɪn ə sɝkəl ɝaʊn ðə θɹi. səm ivən tʃɹaɪd ðɛɹ hæn ət ðə lɛsənz tɑm tɔt, læfɪŋ ət ðɛɹ oʊn fʌmbəlɪŋz. dʒɛlb stʊɾ əloʊn ən wɑtʃt ɪɾ ɔl dɑɹkli, heɪɾɪŋ əm ɔl.

Crewmen who were not working always gathered, squatting in a circle around the three. Some even tried their hand at the lessons Thom taught, laughing at their own fumblings. Gelb stood alone and watched it all darkly, hating them all.

ə ɡʊd pɑɹɾ ʌv itʃ deɪ ɹænd spɛn linɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ʃɔɹ. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðəɾ i ɹɪli ɪkspɛktəd tə si ɛɡwin əɹ ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz sʌɾənli əpɪɹ ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝbæŋk, bʌt ðə boʊt tʃɹævəl soʊ sloʊli ðəɾ i səmtaɪmz hoʊp fəɹ ɪt. ðeɪ kəd kætʃ ʌp wɪθaʊt ɹaɪɾɪŋ tu hɑɹd. ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ɪskeɪpt. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ stɪl əlaɪv.

A good part of each day Rand spent leaning on the railing, staring at the shore. It was not that he really expected to see Egwene or any of the others suddenly appear on the riverbank, but the boat traveled so slowly that he sometimes hoped for it. They could catch up without riding too hard. If they had escaped. If they were still alive.

ðə ɹɪvɝ ɹoʊld ɑn wɪθaʊɾ ɛni saɪn ə laɪf, nɔɹ ɛni boʊt tə bi sin ɪksɛp ðə spɹeɪ. bʌt ðət wɑz nɑt tə seɪ ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ tə si, ən wʌndɝ æt. ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə fɝs deɪ, ði ɑɹɪnɛl ɹæn bɪtwin haɪ blʌfs ðət stʃɹɛtʃt fəɹ hæf ə maɪl ɑn iðɝ saɪd. fəɹ ðət hoʊl lɛŋθ ðə stoʊn hæd bɪn kʌɾ ɪndə fɪɡjɝz, mɛn ən wɪmən ə hʌnʒɹəd fit tɔl, wɪð kɹaʊnz pɹoʊkleɪmɪŋ əm kɪŋz ən kwinz. noʊ tu wɝ əlaɪk ɪn ðət ɹɔɪəl pɹəsɛʃən, ən lɔŋ jɪɹz sɛpɝeɪɾəd ðə fɝs fɹəm ðə læst. wɪn ən ɹeɪn hæd wɔɹn ðoʊz ət ðə nɔɹθ ɛn smuð ən ɔlmoʊs fitʃɝləs, wɪð feɪsəz ən dɪteɪlz bɪkʌmɪŋ mɔɹ dɪstɪŋkt əz ðeɪ wɛn saʊθ. ðə ɹɪvɝ læpt ɝaʊn ðə stætʃuz' fit, fit wɑʃt tə smuð nʌbz, ðoʊz ðət wɝ nɑt ɡɔn kəmplitli. haʊ lɔŋ əv ðeɪ stʊd ðɛɹ, ɹænd wʌndɝd. haʊ lɔŋ fəɹ ðə ɹɪvɝ tə wɛɹ əweɪ soʊ mʌtʃ stoʊn? nʌn ə ðə kɹu soʊ mʌtʃ əz lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ðɛɹ wɝk, ðeɪ hæd sin ði eɪntʃən kɑɹvɪŋz soʊ mɛni taɪmz bɪfɔɹ.

The river rolled on without any sign of life, nor any boat to be seen except the Spray. But that was not to say there was nothing to see, and wonder at. In the middle of the first day, the Arinelle ran between high bluffs that stretched for half a mile on either side. For that whole length the stone had been cut into figures, men and women a hundred feet tall, with crowns proclaiming them kings and queens. No two were alike in that royal procession, and long years separated the first from the last. Wind and rain had worn those at the north end smooth and almost featureless, with faces and details becoming more distinct as they went south. The river lapped around the statues' feet, feet washed to smooth nubs, those that were not gone completely. How long have they stood there, Rand wondered. How long for the river to wear away so much stone? None of the crew so much as looked up from their work, they had seen the ancient carvings so many times before.

ənʌðɝ taɪm, wən ði istwɝd ʃɔɹ hæd bɪkʌm flæt ɡɹæslæn əɡɛn, bɹoʊkən oʊnli əkeɪʒənəli baɪ θɪkəts; ðə sʌn ɡlɪntɪɾ ɔf sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə dɪstəns. "wʌt kən ðət bi?" ɹænd wʌndɝɾ əlaʊd. "ɪt lʊks laɪk mɛɾəl."

Another time, when the eastward shore had become flat grassland again, broken only occasionally by thickets; the sun glinted off something in the distance. "What can that be?" Rand wondered aloud. "It looks like metal."

kæptən doʊmən wɑz wɔkɪŋ baɪ, ən i pɔzd, skwɪntɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɡlɪnt. "ɪt də bi mɛɾəl," hi sɛd. hɪz wɝdz stɪl ɹæn təɡɛðɝ, bʌt ɹænd hæd kʌm tə ʌndɝstænd wɪθaʊt hævɪŋ tə pʌzəl ɪɾ aʊt. "ə taʊɝ ə mɛɾəl. aɪ hæv sin ɪt kloʊs ʌp, ən aɪ noʊ. ɹɪvɝ tʃɹeɪɾɝz juz ɪɾ əz ə mɑɹkɝ. wi bi tɛn deɪz fɹəm waɪtbɹɪdʒ ət ðə ɹeɪt wi ɡoʊ."

Captain Domon was walking by, and he paused, squinting toward the glint. "It do be metal," he said. His words still ran together, but Rand had come to understand without having to puzzle it out. "A tower of metal. I have seen it close up, and I know. River traders use it as a marker. We be ten days from Whitebridge at the rate we go."

"ə mɛɾəl taʊɝ?" ɹænd sɛd, ən mæt, sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəd wɪð ɪz bæk əɡɛnst ə bæɹəl, ɹaʊz fɹəm ɪz bɹuɾɪŋ tə lɪsən.

"A metal tower?" Rand said, and Mat, sitting cross-legged with his back against a barrel, roused from his brooding to listen.

ðə kæptən nɑɾəd. "aɪ. ʃaɪnɪŋ stil, baɪ ðə lʊk ən fil ʌv ɪt, bʌt noʊ ə spɑɾ ə ɹʌst. tu hʌnʒɹəd fit haɪ, ɪt bi, əz bɪɡ ɝaʊn əz ə haʊs, wɪð noʊ ə mɑɹk ɑn ɪɾ ən nɛvɝ ən oʊpənɪŋ tə bi faʊnd."

The captain nodded. "Aye. Shining steel, by the look and feel of it, but no a spot of rust. Two hundred feet high, it be, as big around as a house, with no a mark on it and never an opening to be found."

"aɪl bɛt ðɛɹz tʃɹɛʒɝ ɪnsaɪd," mæt sɛd. hi stʊɾ ʌp ən stɛɹd təwɔɹd ðə fɑɹ taʊɝ əz ðə ɹɪvɝ kæɹid ðə spɹeɪ bɪɑn ɪt. "ə θɪŋ laɪk ðət mʌst əv bɪn meɪd tə pɹətɛk sʌmθɪŋ væljəbəl."

"I'll bet there's treasure inside," Mat said. He stood up and stared toward the far tower as the river carried the Spray beyond it. "A thing like that must have been made to protect something valuable."

"meɪæp, læd," ðə kæptən ɹʌmbəld. "ðɛɹ bi stʃɹeɪnʒɝ θɪŋz ɪn ðə wɝl ðən ðɪs, ðoʊ. ɑn tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ, wʌn ə ðə si foʊks aɪlz, ðəɹ bi ə stoʊn hæn fɪfti fit haɪ stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə hɪl, klʌtʃɪŋ ə kɹɪstəl sfɪɹ əz bɪɡ əz ðɪs vɛsəl. ðəɹ bi tʃɹɛʒɝ ʌndɝ ðət hɪl ɪf ðəɹ bi tʃɹɛʒɝ ɛniwɛɹ, bʌt ði aɪlən pipəl wɑnt noʊ pɑɹɾ ə dɪɡɪŋ ðɛɹ, ən ðə si foʊk kɛɹ fəɹ nɔt bʌt seɪlɪŋ ðɛɹ ʃɪps ən sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ ðə kɔɹəmʊɹ, ðɛɹ tʃoʊzən wʌn."

"Mayhap, lad," the captain rumbled. "There be stranger things in the world than this, though. On Tremalking, one of the Sea Folk's isles, there be a stone hand fifty feet high sticking out of a hill, clutching a crystal sphere as big as this vessel. There be treasure under that hill if there be treasure anywhere, but the island people want no part of digging there, and the Sea Folk care for naught but sailing their ships and searching for the Coramoor, their Chosen One."

"aɪd dɪɡ," mæt sɛd. "haʊ fɑɹ ɪz ðɪs . . . tʃɹɛmælkɪŋ?" ə klʌmp ə tʃɹiz slɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ taʊɝ, bʌɾ i stɛɹɾ əz ɪf i kəd si ɪt jɛt.

"I'd dig," Mat said. "How far is this . . . Tremalking?" A clump of trees slid in front of the shining tower, but he stared as if he could see it yet.

kæptən doʊmən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "noʊ, læd, ɪt noʊ bi ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ ðət meɪks fəɹ siɪŋ ðə wɝld. ɪf jə faɪn jɝsɛlf ə fɪsfəl ʌv ɡoʊld, əɹ səm dɛd kɪŋz dʒuəlz, ɔl wɛl ən ɡʊd, bʌɾ ɪt bi ðə stʃɹeɪnʒnəs jə si ðət pʊlz jə tə ðə nɛks hɝaɪzən. ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ - ðət bi ə pɔɹɾ ɑn ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən - pɑɹɾ ə ðə pɑnɑɹtʃəz pæləs wɝ bɪlt ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, soʊ ɪt bi sɛd. ðəɹ bi ə wɔl ðəɹ wɪð ə fɹiz ʃoʊɪŋ ænəməlz noʊ mæn lɪvɪŋ əz ɛvɝ sin."

Captain Domon shook his head. "No, lad, it no be the treasure that makes for seeing the world. If you find yourself a fistful of gold, or some dead king's jewels, all well and good, but it be the strangeness you see that pulls you to the next horizon. In Tanchico - that be a port on the Aryth Ocean - part of the Panarch's Palace were built in the Age of Legends, so it be said. There be a wall there with a frieze showing animals no man living has ever seen."

"ɛni tʃaɪl kən dʒɹɔ ən ænəməl noʊbɑdiz ɛvɝ sin," ɹænd sɛd, ən ðə kæptən tʃʌkəld.

"Any child can draw an animal nobody's ever seen," Rand said, and the captain chuckled.

"aɪ, læd, soʊ ðeɪ kæn. bʌt kən ə tʃaɪl meɪk ðə boʊnz ə ðoʊz ænəməlz? ɪn tæntʃəkoʊ ðeɪv ðɛm, ɔl fæsən təɡɛðɝ laɪk ði ænəməl wɑz. ðeɪ stæn ɪn ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə pɑnɑɹtʃəz pæləs wɛɹ ɛni kən ɛntɝ ən si. ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ lɛft ə θaʊzənd wʌndɝz bɪhaɪnd, ən ðəɹ bɪn hæf ə dʌzən ɛmpaɪɝz əɹ mɔɹ sɪns, səm ɹaɪvəlɪŋ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz, ɛvɹi wʌn livɪŋ θɪŋz tə si ən faɪnd. laɪtstɪks ən ɹeɪzɝleɪs ən hɑɹtstoʊn. ə kɹɪstəl læɾəs kʌvɝɪŋ ən aɪlənd, ən ɪt hʌmz wən ðə mun ɪz ʌp. ə maʊntən hɑloʊɾ ɪndə ə boʊl, ən ɪn ɪts sɛntɝ, ə sɪlvɝ spaɪk ə hʌnʒɹəd spænz haɪ, ən ɛni hu kʌmz wɪðɪn ə maɪl ʌv ɪt, daɪz. ɹʌstəd ɹuənz, ən bɹoʊkən bɪts, ən θɪŋz faʊn ɑn ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə si, θɪŋz nɑɾ ivən ði oʊldəs bʊks noʊ ðə minɪŋ ʌv aɪv ɡæðɝɾ ə fju, maɪsɛlf. θɪŋz jə nɛvɝ dʒɹimd ʌv, ɪn mɔɹ pleɪsəz ðən jə kən si ɪn tɛn laɪftaɪmz. ðət bi ðə stʃɹeɪnʒnəs ðət wɪl dʒɹɔ jə ɑn."

"Aye, lad, so they can. But can a child make the bones of those animals? In Tanchico they have them, all fastened together like the animal was. They stand in a part of the Panarch's Palace where any can enter and see. The Breaking left a thousand wonders behind, and there been half a dozen empires or more since, some rivaling Artur Hawkwing's, every one leaving things to see and find. Lightsticks and razorlace and heartstone. A crystal lattice covering an island, and it hums when the moon is up. A mountain hollowed into a bowl, and in its center, a silver spike a hundred spans high, and any who comes within a mile of it, dies. Rusted ruins, and broken bits, and things found on the bottom of the sea, things not even the oldest books know the meaning of I've gathered a few, myself. Things you never dreamed of, in more places than you can see in ten lifetimes. That be the strangeness that will draw you on."

"wi juz tə dɪɡ ʌp boʊnz ɪn ðə sæn hɪlz," ɹænd sɛd sloʊli. "stʃɹeɪnʒ boʊnz. ðəɹ wɑz pɑɹɾ ʌv ə fɪʃ - aɪ θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ə fɪʃ - əz bɪɡ əz ðɪs boʊt, wʌns. səm sɛɾ ɪt wɑz bæd lʌk, dɪɡɪŋ ɪn ðə hɪlz."

"We used to dig up bones in the Sand Hills," Rand said slowly. "Strange bones. There was part of a fish - I think it was a fish - as big as this boat, once. Some said it was bad luck, digging in the hills."

ðə kæptən aɪɾ ɪm ʃɹudli. "ju θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt hoʊm ɔlɹɛɾi, læd, ən jə dʒʌst sɛɾ aʊɾ ɪn ðə wɝld? ðə wɝld wɪl pʊɾ ə hʊk ɪn jəɹ maʊθ. jəl sɛɾ ɔf tʃeɪsɪŋ ðə sʌnsɛt, jə weɪɾ ən si . . . ən ɪf jə ɛvɝ ɡoʊ bæk, jəɹ vɪlədʒəl noʊ bi bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə hoʊl ju."

The captain eyed him shrewdly. "You thinking about home already, lad, and you just set out in the world? The world will put a hook in your mouth. You'll set off chasing the sunset, you wait and see . . . and if you ever go back, your village'll no be big enough to hold you."

"noʊ!" hi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. haʊ lɔŋ hæɾ ɪt bɪn sɪns i hæd θɔɾ ə hoʊm, ʌv ɛmənz fild? ən wʌɾ ə tæm? ɪt hæd tə bi deɪz. ɪt fɛlt laɪk mʌnθs. "aɪ wɪl ɡoʊ hoʊm, wʌn deɪ, wən aɪ kæn. əl ɹeɪz ʃip, laɪk . . . laɪk maɪ fɑðɝ, ən ɪf aɪ nɛvɝ liv əɡɛn ɪɾəl bi tu sun. ɪzən ðət ɹaɪt, mæt? əz sun əz wi kən wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ hoʊm ən fɝɡɛɾ ɔl ðɪs ivən ɪɡzɪsts."

"No!" He gave a start. How long had it been since he had thought of home, of Emond's Field? And what of Tam? It had to be days. It felt like months. "I will go home, one day, when I can. I'll raise sheep, like . . . like my father, and if I never leave again it will be too soon. Isn't that right, Mat? As soon as we can we're going home and forget all this even exists."

wɪð ə vɪzəbəl ɛfɝt mæt pʊld əweɪ fɹəm stɛɹɪŋ ʌpɹɪvɝ æftɝ ðə vænɪʃt taʊɝ. "wʌt? oʊ. jɛs, ʌv kɔɹs. wɪl ɡoʊ hoʊm. ʌv kɔɹs." əz i tɝn tə ɡoʊ, ɹænd hɝɾ ɪm mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. "aɪl bɛɾ i dʒʌs dʌznt wɑn ɛnibəɾi ɛls ɡoʊɪŋ æftɝ ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ." hi dɪd nɑt sim tə ɹilaɪz i hæd spoʊkən əlaʊd.

With a visible effort Mat pulled away from staring upriver after the vanished tower. "What? Oh. Yes, of course. We'll go home. Of course." As he turned to go, Rand heard him muttering under his breath. "I'll bet he just doesn't want anybody else going after the treasure." He did not seem to realize he had spoken aloud.

fɔɹ deɪz ɪndə ðɛɹ tʃɹɪp daʊnɹɪvɝ faʊn ɹænd ətɑp ðə mæst, sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə blʌn ɛnd wɪð ɪz lɛɡz ɹæpt ɪn ðə steɪz. ðə spɹeɪ ɹoʊl dʒɛnli ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝ, bʌt fɪfti fiɾ əbʌv ðə wɔɾɝ ðəɾ izi ɹoʊl meɪd ðə tɑp ə ðə mæst sweɪ bæk ən fɔɹθ θɹu waɪɾ ɑɹks. hi θɹu bæk ɪz hɛɾ ən læft ɪndə ðə wɪn ðət blu ɪn ɪz feɪs.

Four days into their trip downriver found Rand atop the mast, sitting on the blunt end with his legs wrapped in the stays. The Spray rolled gently on the river, but fifty feet above the water that easy roll made the top of the mast sway back and forth through wide arcs. He threw back his head and laughed into the wind that blew in his face.

ði ɔɹz wɝ aʊt, ən fɹəm hɪɹ ðə boʊt lʊk laɪk səm twɛlv-lɛɡəd spaɪɾɝ kɹipɪŋ daʊn ði ɑɹɪnɛl. hi hæd bɪn əz haɪ əz ðɪs bɪfɔɹ, ɪn tʃɹiz bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, bʌt ðɪs taɪm ðəɹ wɝ noʊ bɹæntʃəz tə blɑk ɪz vju. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɑn dɛk, ðə seɪlɝz ət ðə swips, mɛn ɑn ðɛɹ niz skɹʌbɪŋ ðə dɛk wɪð smuðstoʊnz, mɛn duɪŋ θɪŋz wɪð laɪnz ən hætʃkʌvɝz, lʊk soʊ ɑd wən sin fɹəm ɹaɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd, ɔl skwɑɾ ən fɔɹʃɔɹɾənd, ðəɾ i hæd spɛn ən aʊɝ dʒʌst stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əm ən tʃʌklɪŋ.

The oars were out, and from here the boat looked like some twelve-legged spider creeping down the Arinelle. He had been as high as this before, in trees back in the Two Rivers, but this time there were no branches to block his view. Everything on deck, the sailors at the sweeps, men on their knees scrubbing the deck with smoothstones, men doing things with lines and hatchcovers, looked so odd when seen from right overhead, all squat and foreshortened, that he had spent an hour just staring at them and chuckling.

hi stɪl tʃʌkəld wɛnɛvɝ i lʊk daʊn ət ðɛm, bʌt naʊ hi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ɹɪvɝbɑŋks floʊɪŋ baɪ. ðət wɑz ðə weɪ ɪt simd, əz ɪf i wɝ stɪl - ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə sweɪɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ, ʌv kɔɹs - ən ðə bæŋks slɪd sloʊli baɪ, tʃɹiz ən hɪlz mɑɹtʃɪŋ əlɔŋ tə iðɝ saɪd. hi wɑz stɪl, ən ðə hoʊl wɝl muv pæs hɪm.

He still chuckled whenever he looked down at them, but now he was staring at the riverbanks flowing by. That was the way it seemed, as if he were still - except for the swaying back and forth, of course - and the banks slid slowly by, trees and hills marching along to either side. He was still, and the whole world moved past him.

ɑn sʌɾən ɪmpəls i ənɹæpt ɪz lɛɡz fɹəm ðə steɪz bɹeɪsɪŋ ðə mæst ən hɛld ɪz ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz aʊt tə iðɝ saɪd, bælənsɪŋ əɡɛns ðə sweɪ. fəɹ θɹi kəmpliɾ ɑɹks i kɛpt ɪz bæləns laɪk ðæt, ðən sʌɾənli ɪt wɑz ɡɔn. ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz wɪndmɪlɪŋ, hi tɑpəl fɔɹwɝɾ ən ɡɹæb ðə fɔɹsteɪ. lɛɡz spleɪd tə iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə mæst, nʌθɪŋ hoʊldɪŋ ɪm tə hɪz pɹikɛɹiəs pɝtʃ bʌɾ ɪz tu hænz ɑn ðə steɪ, hi læft. ɡʌlpɪŋ hjudʒ bɹɛθs ə ðə fɹɛʃ, koʊld wɪnd, hi læft wɪð ði ɪɡzɪlɝeɪʃən ʌv ɪt.

On sudden impulse he unwrapped his legs from the stays bracing the mast and held his arms and legs out to either side, balancing against the sway. For three complete arcs he kept his balance like that, then suddenly it was gone. Arms and legs windmilling, he toppled forward and grabbed the forestay. Legs splayed to either side of the mast, nothing holding him to his precarious perch but his two hands on the stay, he laughed. Gulping huge breaths of the fresh, cold wind, he laughed with the exhilaration of it.

"læd," keɪm tɑmz hɔɹs vɔɪs. "læd, ɪf jəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɹeɪk jəɹ ful nɛk, doʊn də ɪt baɪ fɔlɪŋ ɑn mi."

"Lad," came Thom's hoarse voice. "Lad, if you're trying to break your fool neck, don't do it by falling on me."

ɹænd lʊk daʊn. tɑm klʌŋ tə ðə ɹætlaɪnz dʒʌs bɪloʊ hɪm, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ðə læs fju fit ɡɹɪmli. laɪk ɹænd, ðə ɡlimən hæd lɛft ɪz kloʊk bɪloʊ. "tɑm," hi sɛd dɪlaɪɾɪdli. "tɑm, wən dɪd jə kʌm ʌp hɪɹ?"

Rand looked down. Thom clung to the ratlines just below him, staring up the last few feet grimly. Like Rand, the gleeman had left his cloak below. "Thom," he said delightedly. "Thom, when did you come up here?"

"wɛn jə wʊdn peɪ ɛni ətɛnʃən tə pipəl ʃaʊɾɪŋ ət ju. bɝn mi, bɔɪ, juv ɡɑɾ ɛvɹibɑɾi θɪŋkɪŋ juv ɡɔn mæd."

"When you wouldn't pay any attention to people shouting at you. Burn me, boy, you've got everybody thinking you've gone mad."

hi lʊk daʊn ən wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si ɔl ðə feɪsəz stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət hɪm. oʊnli mæt, sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ʌp ɪn ðə baʊz wɪð ɪz bæk tə ðə mæst, wɑz nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. ivən ðə mɛn ət ði ɔɹz hæd ðɛɹ aɪz ɹeɪzd, lɛɾɪŋ ðɛɹ stʃɹoʊk ɡoʊ ɹæɡəd. ən noʊ wʌn wɑz bɪɹeɪɾɪŋ əm fəɹ ɪt. ɹænd twɪstəɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɝaʊn tə lʊk ʌndɝ ɪz ɑɹm ət ðə stɝn. kæptən doʊmən stʊd baɪ ðə stɪɹɪŋ ɔɹ, hæm-laɪk fɪsts ɑn ɪz hɪps, ɡlɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm ətɑp ðə mæst. hi tɝn bæk tə ɡɹɪn ət tɑm. "ju wɑn mi tə kʌm daʊn, ðɛn?"

He looked down and was surprised to see all the faces staring up at him. Only Mat, sitting cross-legged up in the bows with his back to the mast, was not looking at him. Even the men at the oars had their eyes raised, letting their stroke go ragged. And no one was berating them for it. Rand twisted his head around to look under his arm at the stern. Captain Domon stood by the steering oar, ham-like fists on his hips, glaring at him atop the mast. He turned back to grin at Thom. "You want me to come down, then?"

tɑm nɑɾəd vɪɡɝəsli. "aɪ wəɾ əpɹiʃieɪɾ ɪt ɡɹeɪtli."

Thom nodded vigorously. "I would appreciate it greatly."

"ɔl ɹaɪt." ʃɪftɪŋ ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ðə fɔɹsteɪ, hi spɹæŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ɔf ðə mæs tɑp. hi hɝd tɑm baɪɾ ɔf ən oʊθ əz ɪz fɔl wɑz kʌt ʃɔɹɾ ən i dæŋɡəl fɹəm ðə fɔɹsteɪ baɪ hɪz hænz. ðə ɡlimən skaʊld ət hɪm, wʌn hæn hæf stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt tə kætʃ hɪm. hi ɡɹɪn ət tɑm əɡɛn. "aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ daʊn naʊ."

"All right." Shifting his grip on the forestay, he sprang forward off the mast top. He heard Thom bite off an oath as his fall was cut short and he dangled from the forestay by his hands. The gleeman scowled at him, one hand half stretched out to catch him. He grinned at Thom again. "I'm going down now."

swɪŋɪŋ ɪz lɛɡz ʌp, hi hʊkt wʌn ni oʊvɝ ðə θɪk laɪn ðət ɹæn fɹəm ðə mæs tə ðə baʊ, ðən kɑɾ ɪɾ ɪn ðə kɹʊk ə hɪz ɛlboʊ ən lɛt ɡoʊ wɪð ɪz hænz. sloʊli, ðən wɪð ɪnkɹisɪŋ spid, hi slɪd daʊn. dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə baʊ hi dʒɹɑp tə hɪz fiɾ ɑn ðə dɛk ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə mæt, tʊk wʌn stɛp tə kætʃ ɪz bæləns, ən tɝn tə feɪs ðə boʊt wɪð ɑɹmz spɹɛd waɪd, ðə weɪ tɑm dɪɾ æftɝ ə tʌmbəlɪŋ tʃɹɪk.

Swinging his legs up, he hooked one knee over the thick line that ran from the mast to the bow, then caught it in the crook of his elbow and let go with his hands. Slowly, then with increasing speed, he slid down. Just short of the bow he dropped to his feet on the deck right in front of Mat, took one step to catch his balance, and turned to face the boat with arms spread wide, the way Thom did after a tumbling trick.

skæɾɝd klæpɪŋ ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə kɹu, bʌɾ i wɑz lʊkɪŋ daʊn ət mæt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, ən ət wʌt mæt hɛld, hɪɾən fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls baɪ hɪz bɑɾi. ə kɝv dæɡɝ wɪð ə ɡoʊl skæbɝd wɝkt ɪn stʃɹeɪnʒ sɪmbəlz. faɪn ɡoʊld waɪɝ ɹæp ðə hɪlt, wɪtʃ wɑz kæp baɪ ə ɹubi əz bɪɡ əz ɹændz θʌmneɪl, ən ðə kwɪlənz wɝ ɡoʊldən-skeɪl sɝpəns bɛɹɪŋ ðɛɹ fæŋz.

Scattered clapping rose from the crew, but he was looking down at Mat in surprise, and at what Mat held, hidden from everyone else by his body. A curved dagger with a gold scabbard worked in strange symbols. Fine gold wire wrapped the hilt, which was capped by a ruby as big as Rand's thumbnail, and the quillons were golden-scaled serpents baring their fangs.

mæt kəntɪnjud tə slaɪd ðə dæɡɝ ɪn ən aʊɾ ʌv ɪts ʃiθ fəɹ ə moʊmənt. stɪl pleɪɪŋ wɪð ðə dæɡɝ i ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛd sloʊli; hɪz aɪz hæɾ ə fɑɹəweɪ lʊk. sʌɾənli ðeɪ foʊkəst ɑn ɹænd, ən i ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən stʌf ðə dæɡɝ ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt.

Mat continued to slide the dagger in and out of its sheath for a moment. Still playing with the dagger he raised his head slowly; his eyes had a faraway look. Suddenly they focused on Rand, and he gave a start and stuffed the dagger under his coat.

ɹænd skwɑɾɪd ɑn ɪz hilz, wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz kɹɔst ɑn ɪz niz. "wɛɹ dɪd jə ɡɛt ðæt?" mæt sɛd nʌθɪŋ, lʊkɪŋ kwɪkli tə si ɪf ɛniwʌn ɛls wɑz kloʊs baɪ. ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn, fəɹ ə wʌndɝ. "ju dɪdn teɪk ɪt fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, dɪd ju?"

Rand squatted on his heels, with his arms crossed on his knees. "Where did you get that?" Mat said nothing, looking quickly to see if anyone else was close by. They were alone, for a wonder. "You didn't take it from Shadar Logoth, did you?"

mæt stɛɹɾ ət hɪm. "ɪts jəɹ fɔlt. jʊɹz ən pɛɹɪnz. ðə tu ʌv jə pʊl mi əweɪ fɹəm ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ, ən aɪ hæɾ ɪɾ ɪn maɪ hænd. mɔɹɾɪθ dɪdnt ɡɪv ɪt tə mi. aɪ tʊk ɪt, soʊ mɔɪɹeɪnz wɔɹnɪŋz əbaʊɾ ɪz ɡɪfs doʊn kaʊnt. jə woʊn tɛl ɛnibəɾi, ɹænd. ðeɪ maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə stil ɪt."

Mat stared at him. "It's your fault. Yours and Perrin's. The two of you pulled me away from the treasure, and I had it in my hand. Mordeth didn't give it to me. I took it, so Moiraine's warnings about his gifts don't count. You won't tell anybody, Rand. They might try to steal it."

"aɪ woʊn tɛl ɛnibəɾi," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪ θɪŋk kæptən doʊmən ɪz ɑnəst, bʌɾ aɪ wʊdn pʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ pæs ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm, ɪspɛʃli dʒɛlb."

"I won't tell anybody," Rand said. "I think Captain Domon is honest, but I wouldn't put anything past the rest of them, especially Gelb."

"nɑɾ ɛnibəɾi," mæt ɪnsɪstəd. "nɑt doʊmən, nɑt tɑm, nɑɾ ɛnibəɾi. wɝ ði oʊnli tu lɛft fɹəm ɛmənz fild, ɹænd. wi kæn əfɔɹd tə tʃɹʌst ɛnibəɾi ɛls."

"Not anybody," Mat insisted. "Not Domon, not Thom, not anybody. We're the only two left from Emond's Field, Rand. We can't afford to trust anybody else."

"ðeɪɹ əlaɪv, mæt. ɛɡwin, ən pɛɹɪn. aɪ noʊ ðəɹ əlaɪv." mæt lʊkt əʃeɪmd. "aɪl kip jəɹ sikɹət, ðoʊ. dʒʌs ðə tu ʌv ʌs. ət list wi doʊn əv tə wɝi əbaʊt mʌni naʊ. wi kən sɛl ɪt fəɹ ɪnʌf tə tʃɹævəl tə tɑɹ vəlɑn laɪk kɪŋz."

"They're alive, Mat. Egwene, and Perrin. I know they're alive." Mat looked ashamed. "I'll keep your secret, though. Just the two of us. At least we don't have to worry about money now. We can sell it for enough to travel to Tar Valon like kings."

"ʌv kɔɹs," mæt sɛɾ æftɝ ə mɪnət. "ɪf wɪv tə. dʒʌs doʊn tɛl ɛnibəɾi əntɪl aɪ seɪ soʊ."

"Of course," Mat said after a minute. "If we have to. Just don't tell anybody until I say so."

"aɪ sɛɾ aɪ wʊdnt. lɪsən, hæv jə hæɾ ɛni mɔɹ dʒɹimz sɪns wi keɪm ɑn ðə boʊt? laɪk ɪn bɛɹlən? ðɪs ɪz ðə fɝs tʃæns aɪv hæd tə æsk wɪθaʊt sɪks pipəl lɪsnɪŋ."

"I said I wouldn't. Listen, have you had any more dreams since we came on the boat? Like in Baerlon? This is the first chance I've had to ask without six people listening."

mæt tɝn ɪz hɛɾ əweɪ, ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ lʊk. "meɪbi."

Mat turned his head away, giving him a sidelong look. "Maybe."

"wʌt dʒju min, meɪbi? iðɝ juv əɹ jə hævənt."

"What do you mean, maybe? Either you have or you haven't."

"ɔl ɹaɪt, ɔl ɹaɪt, aɪ hæv. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt. aɪ doʊn ivən wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪt. ɪt dʌzn də ɛni ɡʊd."

"All right, all right, I have. I don't want to talk about it. I don't even want to think about it. It doesn't do any good."

bɪfɔɹ iðɝ ə ðɛm kəd seɪ mɔɹ tɑm keɪm stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ ʌp ðə dɛk, hɪz kloʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ɑɹm. ðə wɪnd wɪpt ɪz waɪt hɛɹ əbaʊt, ən ɪz lɔŋ mʌstæʃɪz sim tə bɹɪsəl. "aɪ mænədʒ tə kənvɪns ðə kæptən jə ɑɹən kɹeɪzi," hi ənaʊnst, "ðæɾ ɪt wɑz pɑɹɾ ə jəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ." hi kɑt hoʊld ə ðə fɔɹsteɪ ən ʃʊk ɪt. "ðæt ful stʌn ə jʊɹz, slaɪɾɪŋ daʊn ðə ɹoʊp, hɛlpt, bʌt jə ɑɹ lʌki jə dɪdn bɹeɪk jəɹ ful nɛk."

Before either of them could say more Thom came striding up the deck, his cloak over his arm. The wind whipped his white hair about, and his long mustaches seemed to bristle. "I managed to convince the captain you aren't crazy," he announced, "that it was part of your training." He caught hold of the forestay and shook it. "That fool stunt of yours, sliding down the rope, helped, but you are lucky you didn't break your fool neck."

ɹændz aɪz wɛn tə ðə fɔɹsteɪ ən fɑloʊɾ ɪɾ ʌp tə ðə tɑp ə ðə mæst, ən əz ðeɪ dɪɾ ɪz maʊθ dʒɹɑpt oʊpən. hi hæd slɪd daʊn ðæt. ən i hæd bɪn sɪɾɪŋ ɑn tɑp ʌv. . . .

Rand's eyes went to the forestay and followed it up to the top of the mast, and as they did his mouth dropped open. He had slid down that. And he had been sitting on top of. . . .

sʌɾənli hi kəd si hɪmsɛlf ʌp ðɛɹ, ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz spɹɛd waɪd. hi sæt daʊn hɑɹd, ən bɛɹli kɑt hɪmsɛlf ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ɛndɪŋ ʌp flæɾ ɑn ɪz bæk. tɑm wɑz lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm θɔtfəli.

Suddenly he could see himself up there, arms and legs spread wide. He sat down hard, and barely caught himself short of ending up flat on his back. Thom was looking at him thoughtfully.

"aɪ dɪdnt noʊ jə hæd sətʃ ə ɡʊd hɛd fəɹ haɪts, læd. wi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə pleɪ ɪn ɪljən, əɹ ɛbu dɑɹ, əɹ ivən tɛɹ. pipəl ɪn ðə bɪɡ sɪɾiz ɪn ðə saʊθ laɪk taɪtʃɹoʊp wɔkɝz ən slækwaɪɹ ɑɹɾəsts."

"I didn't know you had such a good head for heights, lad. We might be able to play in Illian, or Ebou Dar, or even Tear. People in the big cities in the south like tightrope walkers and slackwire artists."

"wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə - " ət ðə læs mɪnət ɹænd ɹɪmɛmbɝd tə lʊk ɝaʊn fəɹ ɛniwʌn kloʊs ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝhɪɹ. sɛvɹəl ə ðə kɹu wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ðɛm, ɪnkluɾɪŋ dʒɛlb, ɡlɛɹɪŋ əz juʒəwəl, bʌt nʌn kəd hɪɹ wʌɾ i wɑz seɪɪŋ. "tə tɑɹ vəlɑn," hi fɪnɪʃt. mæt ʃɹʌɡd əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ɔl ðə seɪm tə hɪm wɛɹ ðeɪ wɛnt.

"We're going to - " At the last minute Rand remembered to look around for anyone close enough to overhear. Several of the crew were watching them, including Gelb, glaring as usual, but none could hear what he was saying. "To Tar Valon," he finished. Mat shrugged as if it were all the same to him where they went.

"æt ðə moʊmənt, læd," tɑm sɛd, sɛɾəlɪŋ daʊn bɪsaɪd ðɛm, "bʌt təmɑɹoʊ . . . hu noʊz? ðæts ðə weɪ wɪð ə ɡlimənz laɪf." hi tʊk ə hændfʊl ə kʌlɝd bɔlz fɹəm wʌn ə hɪz waɪd slivz. "sɪns aɪ hæv jə daʊn aʊɾ ə ði ɛɹ, wɪl wɝk ɑn ðə tʃɹɪpəl kɹɔsoʊvɝ."

"At the moment, lad," Thom said, settling down beside them, "but tomorrow . . . who knows? That's the way with a gleeman's life." He took a handful of colored balls from one of his wide sleeves. "Since I have you down out of the air, we'll work on the triple crossover."

ɹændz ɡeɪz dʒɹɪftəd tə ðə tɑp ə ðə mæst, ən i ʃɪvɝd. wʌts hæpənɪŋ tə mi? laɪt, wʌt? hi hæd tə faɪn aʊt. hi hæd tə ɡɛt tə tɑɹ vəlɑn bɪfɔɹ i ɹɪli dɪd ɡoʊ mæd.

Rand's gaze drifted to the top of the mast, and he shivered. What's happening to me? Light, what? He had to find out. He had to get to Tar Valon before he really did go mad.


tʃæptɝ twɛntifaɪv


CHAPTER 25

ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl


The Traveling People

bɛlə wɔkt əlɔŋ plɑtʃədli ʌndɝ ðə wik sʌn əz ɪf ðə θɹi wʊlvz tʃɹɑɾɪŋ nɑt fɑɹ ɔf wɝ oʊnli vɪlədʒ dɑɡz, bʌt ðə weɪ ʃi ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz əɾ əm fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm, ʃoʊɪŋ waɪɾ ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊnd, ɪndəkeɪɾəd ʃi fɛl nʌθɪŋ ə ðə sɔɹt. ɛɡwin, ɑn ðə mɛɹz bæk, wɑz dʒʌst əz bæd. ʃi wɑtʃt ðə wʊlvz kɑnstənli fɹəm ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɝ aɪ, ən səmtaɪmz ʃi twɪstəɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəl tə lʊk ɝaʊnd. pɛɹɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi wɑz hʌntɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə pæk, ðoʊ ʃi dɪnaɪɾ ɪɾ æŋɡɹəli wən i sədʒɛstəɾ əz mʌtʃ, dɪnaɪd biɪŋ əfɹeɪɾ ə ðə wʊlvz ðət peɪs ðɛm, dɪnaɪd wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ðə ɹɛst ə ðə pæk əɹ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ʌp tə. ʃi dɪnaɪd, ən wɛn ɹaɪɾ ɑn lʊkɪŋ, taɪt-aɪɾ ən wɛɾɪŋ əɹ lɪps ənizəli.

Bela walked along placidly under the weak sun as if the three wolves trotting not far off were only village dogs, but the way she rolled her eyes at them from time to time, showing white all the way around, indicated she felt nothing of the sort. Egwene, on the mare's back, was just as bad. She watched the wolves constantly from the corner of her eye, and sometimes she twisted in the saddle to look around. Perrin was sure she was hunting for the rest of the pack, though she denied it angrily when he suggested as much, denied being afraid of the wolves that paced them, denied worrying about the rest of the pack or what it was up to. She denied, and went right on looking, tight-eyed and wetting her lips uneasily.

ðə ɹɛst ə ðə pæk wɑz fɑɹ dɪstənt; hi cʊɾə toʊld əɹ ðæt. wʌt ɡʊd, ivən ɪf ʃi bɪliv mi? ɪspɛʃli ɪf ʃi dɪd. hi wɑz ə noʊ maɪn tə oʊpən ðət bæskəɾ ə sneɪks əntɪl i hæd tə. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt haʊ hi nu. ðə fɝ-klæd mæn loʊpt əhɛɾ ə ðɛm, səmtaɪmz lʊkɪŋ ɔlmoʊs laɪk ə wʊlf hɪmsɛlf, ən i nɛvɝ lʊkt ɝaʊnd wən dæpəl, hɑpɝ, ən wɪn əpɪɹd, bʌɾ i nu, tu.

The rest of the pack was far distant; he could have told her that. What good, even if she believed me? Especially if she did. He was of no mind to open that basket of snakes until he had to. He did not want to think about how he knew. The fur-clad man loped ahead of them, sometimes looking almost like a wolf himself, and he never looked around when Dapple, Hopper, and Wind appeared, but he knew, too.

ði ɛmənz fildɝz hæd wækən ət dɔn ðət fɝs mɔɹnɪŋ tə faɪn ɛlaɪəs kʊkɪŋ mɔɹ ɹæbəɾ ən wɑtʃɪŋ əm oʊvɝ ɪz fʊl bɪɹd wɪθaʊt mʌtʃ ɪkspɹɛʃən. ɪksɛp fəɹ dæpəl, hɑpɝ, ən waɪnd, noʊ wʊlvz wɝ tə bi sin. ɪn ðə peɪl, ɝli deɪlaɪt, dip ʃeɪd stɪl lɪŋɡɝɾ ʌndɝ ðə bɪɡ oʊk, ən ðə bɛɹ tʃɹiz bɪɑn lʊk laɪk fɪŋɡɝz stʃɹɪp tə ðə boʊn.

The Emond's Fielders had wakened at dawn that first morning to find Elyas cooking more rabbit and watching them over his full beard without much expression. Except for Dapple, Hopper, and Wind, no wolves were to be seen. In the pale, early daylight, deep shade still lingered under the big oak, and the bare trees beyond looked like fingers stripped to the bone.

"ðeɪɹ ɝaʊnd," ɛlaɪəs ænsɝd wən ɛɡwin æskt wɛɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə pæk hæd ɡɔn. "kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɛlp, ɪf nid bi. fɑɹ ɪnʌf ɔf tə əvɔɪɾ ɛni hjumən tʃɹʌbəl wi ɡɛɾ ɪntu. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ðɛɹz ɔlweɪz tʃɹʌbəl wən ðɛɹz tu hjumənz təɡɛðɝ. ɪf wi nid ðɛm, ðəl bi ðɛɹ."

"They're around," Elyas answered when Egwene asked where the rest of the pack had gone. "Close enough to help, if need be. Far enough off to avoid any human trouble we get into. Sooner or later there's always trouble when there's two humans together. If we need them, they'll be there."

sʌmθɪŋ tɪkəl ðə bæk ə pɛɹɪnz maɪn əz i ɹɪp fɹi ə baɪɾ ə ɹoʊst ɹæbət. ə dɝɛkʃən, veɪɡli sɛnst. ʌv kɔɹs! ðæts wɛɹ ðeɪ. . . . ðə hɑt dʒusəz ɪn ɪz maʊθ əbɹʌpli lɔst ɔl teɪst. hi pɪkt ət ðə təbɝz ɛlaɪəs hæd kʊkt ɪn ðə koʊlz - ðeɪ teɪstəd sʌmθɪŋ laɪk tɝnəps - bʌɾ ɪz æpətaɪt wɑz ɡɔn.

Something tickled the back of Perrin's mind as he ripped free a bite of roast rabbit. A direction, vaguely sensed. Of course! That's where they. . . . The hot juices in his mouth abruptly lost all taste. He picked at the tubers Elyas had cooked in the coals - they tasted something like turnips - but his appetite was gone.

wən ðeɪ hæd stɑɹɾəd aʊɾ ɛɡwin ɪnsɪstəd ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn teɪk ə tɝn ɹaɪɾɪŋ, ən pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑɾ ivən bɑðɝ tə ɑɹɡju.

When they had started out Egwene insisted that everyone take a turn riding, and Perrin did not even bother to argue.

"fɝs tɝn ɪz jʊɹz," hi toʊl hɝ.

"First turn is yours," he told her.

ʃi nɑɾəd. "æn ðən ju, ɛlaɪəs."

She nodded. "And then you, Elyas."

"maɪ oʊn lɛɡz ɑɹ ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ mi," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. hi lʊkt ət bɛlə, ən ðə mɛɹ ɹoʊld əɹ aɪz əz ɪf i wɝ wʌn ə ðə wʊlvz. "bɪsaɪdz, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ʃi wɑns mi ɹaɪɾɪŋ hɝ."

"My own legs are good enough for me," Elyas said. He looked at Bela, and the mare rolled her eyes as if he were one of the wolves. "Besides, I don't think she wants me riding her."

"ðæts nɑnsɛns," ɛɡwin ɹɪplaɪd fɝmli. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn biɪŋ stʌbɝn əbaʊɾ ɪt. ðə sɛnsəbəl θɪŋ ɪz fəɹ ɛvɹibɑɾi tə ɹaɪd səmtaɪmz. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə jə wɪv ə lɔŋ weɪ stɪl tə ɡoʊ."

"That's nonsense," Egwene replied firmly. "There is no point in being stubborn about it. The sensible thing is for everybody to ride sometimes. According to you we have a long way still to go."

"aɪ sɛd noʊ, ɡɝl."

"I said no, girl."

ʃi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ, ən pɛɹɪn wɑz wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ʃi wəd səksiɾ ɪn bʊliɪŋ ɛlaɪəs ðə weɪ ʃi dɪd hɪm, wən i ɹilaɪzd ʃi wɑz stændɪŋ ðəɹ wɪð əɹ maʊθ oʊpən, nɑt seɪɪŋ ə wɝd. ɛlaɪəs wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ, dʒʌs lʊkɪŋ, wɪð ðoʊz jɛloʊ wʊlfs aɪz. ɛɡwin stɛp bæk fɹəm ðə ɹɔ-boʊn mæn, ən lɪkt əɹ lɪps, ən stɛp bæk əɡɛn. bɪfɔɹ ɛlaɪəs tɝn əweɪ, ʃi hæd bækt ɔl ðə weɪ tə bɛlə ən skɹæmbəld ʌp ɑntu ðə mɛɹz bæk. əz ðə mæn tɝn tə liɾ əm saʊθ, pɛɹɪn θɔɾ ɪz ɡɹɪn wɑz ə ɡʊd dil laɪk ə wʊlfs, tu.

She took a deep breath, and Perrin was wondering if she would succeed in bullying Elyas the way she did him, when he realized she was standing there with her mouth open, not saying a word. Elyas was looking at her, just looking, with those yellow wolf's eyes. Egwene stepped back from the raw-boned man, and licked her lips, and stepped back again. Before Elyas turned away, she had backed all the way to Bela and scrambled up onto the mare's back. As the man turned to lead them south, Perrin thought his grin was a good deal like a wolf's, too.

fəɹ θɹi deɪz ðeɪ tʃɹævəld ɪn ðət mænɝ, wɔkɪŋ ən ɹaɪɾɪŋ saʊθ ən ist ɔl deɪ, stɑpɪŋ oʊnli wən twaɪlaɪt θɪkənd. ɛlaɪəs sim tə skɔɹn ðə heɪst ə sɪɾi mɛn, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪn weɪstɪŋ taɪm wən ðəɹ wɑz sʌmwɛɹ tə ɡoʊ.

For three days they traveled in that manner, walking and riding south and east all day, stopping only when twilight thickened. Elyas seemed to scorn the haste of city men, but he did not believe in wasting time when there was somewhere to go.

ðə θɹi wʊlvz wɝ sɛldəm sin. itʃ naɪt ðeɪ keɪm tə ðə faɪɝ fəɹ ə taɪm, ən səmtaɪmz ɪn ðə deɪ ðeɪ ʃoʊd ðɛmsɛlvz bɹifli, əpɪɹɪŋ kloʊs ət hænd wən list ɪkspɛktəɾ ən vænɪʃɪŋ ɪn ðə seɪm mænɝ. pɛɹɪn nu ðeɪ wɝ aʊt ðɛɹ, ðoʊ, ən wɛɹ. hi nu wən ðeɪ wɝ skaʊɾɪŋ ðə pæθ əhɛɾ ən wən ðeɪ wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ðə bæktʃɹeɪl. hi nu wən ðeɪ lɛf ðə pæks juʒəwəl hʌntɪŋ ɡɹaʊnz, ən dæpəl sɛn ðə pæk bæk tə weɪt fəɹ hɝ. səmtaɪmz ðə θɹi ðət ɹɪmeɪn feɪɾəd fɹəm ɪz maɪnd, bʌt lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si əɡɛn, hi wɑz əwɛɹ ə ðɛm ɹɪtɝnɪŋ. ivən wən ðə tʃɹiz dwɪndəl tə waɪd-skæɾɝd ɡɹoʊvz sɛpɝeɪɾəd baɪ ɡɹeɪt swɑðz ʌv wɪntɝ-dɛd ɡɹæs, ðeɪ wɝ əz ɡoʊsts wən ðeɪ dɪd nɑt wɑnə bi sin, bʌɾ i cʊɾə pɔɪntəɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ stʃɹeɪɾ əɾ əm əɾ ɛni taɪm. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ haʊ hi nu, ən i tʃɹaɪd tə kənvɪns hɪmsɛlf ðəɾ ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən pleɪɪŋ tʃɹɪks, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd noʊ ɡʊd. dʒʌst əz ɛlaɪəs nu, hi nu.

The three wolves were seldom seen. Each night they came to the fire for a time, and sometimes in the day they showed themselves briefly, appearing close at hand when least expected and vanishing in the same manner. Perrin knew they were out there, though, and where. He knew when they were scouting the path ahead and when they were watching the backtrail. He knew when they left the pack's usual hunting grounds, and Dapple sent the pack back to wait for her.
