Sometimes the three that remained faded from his mind, but long before they were close enough to see again, he was aware of them returning. Even when the trees dwindled to wide-scattered groves separated by great swathes of winter-dead grass, they were as ghosts when they did not want to be seen, but he could have pointed a finger straight at them at any time. He did not know how he knew, and he tried to convince himself that it was just his imagination playing tricks, but it did no good. Just as Elyas knew, he knew.

hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊt wʊlvz, bʌt ðeɪ kɹɛpt ɪndə hɪz θɔts ɔl ðə seɪm. hi hæd nɑt dʒɹimd əbaʊt bælzəmən sɪns miɾɪŋ ɛlaɪəs ən ðə wʊlvz. hɪz dʒɹimz, əz mʌtʃ əz i ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ə ðɛm ɑn weɪkɪŋ, wɝ ʌv ɛvɹideɪ θɪŋz, dʒʌst əz i maɪɾ əv dʒɹimd ət hoʊm . . . bɪfɔɹ bɛɹlən . . . bɪfɔɹ wɪntɝnaɪt. nɔɹməl dʒɹimz - wɪð wʌn ədɪʃən. ɪn ɛvɹi dʒɹim i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðəɹ wɑz ə pɔɪnt wɛɹ i stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm mæstɝ luhənz fɔɹdʒ tə waɪp ðə swɛt fɹəm ɪz feɪs, əɹ tɝn fɹəm dænsɪŋ wɪð ðə vɪlədʒ ɡɝlz ɑn ðə ɡɹin, əɹ lɪftəɾ ɪz hɛd fɹəm ə bʊk ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs, ən wɛðɝ i wɑz aʊtsaɪɾ əɹ ʌndɝ ə ɹuf, ðəɹ wɑz ə wʊlf kloʊs tə hænd. ɔlweɪz ðə wʊlfs bæk wɑz tə hɪm, ən ɔlweɪz i nu - ɪn ðə dʒɹimz ɪt sim ðə nɔɹməl kɔɹs ə θɪŋz, ivən əɾ ælsbɛt luhənz dɪnɝ teɪbəl - ðət ðə wʊlfs jɛloʊ aɪz wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ fəɹ wʌt maɪt kʌm, ɡɑɹɾɪŋ əɡɛnst wʌt maɪt kʌm. oʊnli wən i wɑz əweɪk dɪd ðə dʒɹimz sim stʃɹeɪnʒ.

He tried not thinking about wolves, but they crept into his thoughts all the same. He had not dreamed about Ba'alzamon since meeting Elyas and the wolves. His dreams, as much as he remembered of them on waking, were of everyday things, just as he might have dreamed at home . . . before Baerlon . . . before Winternight. Normal dreams - with one addition. In every dream he remembered there was a point where he straightened from Master Luhhan's forge to wipe the sweat from his face, or turned from dancing with the village girls on the Green, or lifted his head from a book in front of the fireplace, and whether he was outside or under a roof, there was a wolf close to hand. Always the wolf's back was to him, and always he knew - in the dreams it seemed the normal course of things, even at Alsbet Luhhan's dinner table - that the wolf's yellow eyes were watching for what might come, guarding against what might come. Only when he was awake did the dreams seem strange.

θɹi deɪz ðeɪ dʒɝnid, wɪð dæpəl, hɑpɝ, ən wɪn bɹɪŋɪŋ əm ɹæbəts ən skwɝəlz, ən ɛlaɪəs pɔɪntɪŋ aʊt plæns, fju ʌv wɪtʃ pɛɹɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd, əz ɡʊd tə it. wʌns ə ɹæbət bɝst aʊɾ ɔlmoʊs fɹəm ʌndɝ bɛləz hʊvz; bɪfɔɹ pɛɹɪn kəd ɡɛɾ ə stoʊn ɪn ɪz slɪŋ, ɛlaɪəs skjuɝɾ ɪt wɪð ɪz lɔŋ naɪf ət twɛnti peɪsɪz. ənʌðɝ taɪm ɛlaɪəs bɹɔt daʊn ə fæt fɛzənt, ɑn ðə wɪŋ, wɪð ɪz baʊ. ðeɪ eɪt fɑɹ bɛɾɝ ðən ðeɪ hæd wən ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn, bʌt pɛɹɪn wəɾ əz sun əv ɡɔn bæk ɑn ʃɔɹt ɹæʃənz ɪf ɪt hæd mɛn dɪfɹən kʌmpəni. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ ɛɡwin fɛlt, bʌɾ i wʊɾə bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə ɡoʊ hʌŋɡɹi ɪf i kəd də ɪt wɪθaʊt ðə wʊlvz. θɹi deɪz, ɪndə ði æftɝnun.

Three days they journeyed, with Dapple, Hopper, and Wind bringing them rabbits and squirrels, and Elyas pointing out plants, few of which Perrin recognized, as good to eat. Once a rabbit burst out almost from under Bela's hooves; before Perrin could get a stone in his sling, Elyas skewered it with his long knife at twenty paces. Another time Elyas brought down a fat pheasant, on the wing, with his bow. They ate far better than they had when on their own, but Perrin would as soon have gone back on short rations if it had meant different company. He was not sure how Egwene felt, but he would have been willing to go hungry if he could do it without the wolves. Three days, into the afternoon.

ə stæn ə tʃɹiz leɪ əhɛd, lɑɹdʒɝ ðən moʊs ðeɪ hæd sin, ə ɡʊd fɔɹ maɪlz əkɹɔs. ðə sʌn sæt loʊ ɪn ðə wɛstɝn skaɪ, pʊʃɪŋ slæntəd ʃædoʊz ɔf tə ðɛɹ ɹaɪt, ən ðə wɪnd wɑz pɪkɪŋ ʌp. pɛɹɪn fɛl ðə wʊlvz ɡɪv oʊvɝ kɔɹɾɝɪŋ bɪhaɪn əm ən stɑɹt fɔɹwɝd, nɑt hɝiɪŋ. ðeɪ hæd smɛld ən sin nʌθɪŋ deɪnʒɝəs. ɛɡwin wɑz teɪkɪŋ əɹ tɝn ɑn bɛlə. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə stɑɹt lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ə kæmp fəɹ ðə naɪt, ən ðə bɪɡ kɑps wəd sɝv ðə pɝpəs wɛl.

A stand of trees lay ahead, larger than most they had seen, a good four miles across. The sun sat low in the western sky, pushing slanted shadows off to their right, and the wind was picking up. Perrin felt the wolves give over quartering behind them and start forward, not hurrying. They had smelled and seen nothing dangerous. Egwene was taking her turn on Bela. It was time to start looking for a camp for the night, and the big copse would serve the purpose well.

əz ðeɪ keɪm kloʊs tə ðə tʃɹiz, θɹi mæstəfs bɝs fɹəm kʌvɝ, bɹɔdmuzəl dɑɡz əz tɔl əz ðə wʊlvz ən ivən hɛviɝ, tiθ bɛɹɾ ɪn laʊd, ɹʌmbəlɪŋ snɑɹlz. ðeɪ stɑpt ʃɔɹɾ əz sun əz ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ði oʊpən, bʌt noʊ mɔɹ ðən θɝɾi fit sɛpɝeɪɾəd əm fɹəm ðə θɹi pipəl, ən ðɛɹ dɑɹk aɪz kɪndəld wɪð ə kɪlɪŋ laɪt.

As they came close to the trees, three mastiffs burst from cover, broadmuzzled dogs as tall as the wolves and even heavier, teeth bared in loud, rumbling snarls. They stopped short as soon as they were in the open, but no more than thirty feet separated them from the three people, and their dark eyes kindled with a killing light.

bɛlə, ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn ɛdʒ fɹəm ðə wʊlvz, wɪniɾ ən ɔlmoʊst ənsiɾɪd ɛɡwin, bʌt pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɪz slɪŋ wɝlɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪz hɛɾ ɪn ən ɪnstənt. noʊ nid tə juz ði æks ɑn dɑɡz; ə stoʊn ɪn ðə ɹɪbz wəd sɛn ðə wɝs dɔɡ ɹʌnɪŋ.

Bela, already on edge from the wolves, whinnied and almost unseated Egwene, but Perrin had his sling whirling around his head in an instant. No need to use the axe on dogs; a stone in the ribs would send the worst dog running.

ɛlaɪəs weɪvd ə hæn əɾ ɪm wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz fɹəm ðə stɪf-lɛɡəd dɑɡz. "st! nʌn ə ðət naʊ!"

Elyas waved a hand at him without taking his eyes from the stiff-legged dogs. "Hssst! None of that now!"

pɛɹɪn ɡeɪv ɪm ə pʌzəl fɹaʊn, bʌt lɛt ðə slɪŋ sloʊ ɪts spɪn ən faɪnəli fɔl tə hɪz saɪd. ɛɡwin mænədʒ tə ɡɛt bɛlə ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl; ʃi ən ðə mɛɹ boʊθ wɑtʃt ðə dɑɡz wɛɹəli.

Perrin gave him a puzzled frown, but let the sling slow its spin and finally fall to his side. Egwene managed to get Bela under control; she and the mare both watched the dogs warily.

ðə mæstəfs' hækəlz stʊd stɪf, ən ðɛɹ ɪɹz wɝ leɪd bæk, ən ðɛɹ ɡɹaʊlz saʊndəd laɪk ɝθkweɪks. əbɹʌpli ɛlaɪəs ɹeɪzd wʌn fɪŋɡɝ ʃoʊldɝ haɪ ən wɪsəld, ə lɔŋ, ʃɹɪl wɪsəl ðət ɹoʊz haɪɝ ən haɪɝ ən dɪd nɑɾ ɛnd. ðə ɡɹaʊlz kʌɾ ɔf ɹæədli. ðə dɑɡz stɛp bæk, waɪnɪŋ ən tɝnɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛdz əz ɪf ðeɪ wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ bʌt wɝ hɛld. ðɛɹ aɪz ɹɪmeɪn lɑk tə ɛlaɪəsəz fɪŋɡɝ.

The mastiffs' hackles stood stiff, and their ears were laid back, and their growls sounded like earthquakes. Abruptly Elyas raised one finger shoulder high and whistled, a long, shrill whistle that rose higher and higher and did not end. The growls cut off raggedly. The dogs stepped back, whining and turning their heads as if they wanted to go but were held. Their eyes remained locked to Elyas's finger.

sloʊli ɛlaɪəs loʊɝɾ ɪz hænd, ən ðə pɪtʃ ə hɪz wɪsəl loʊɝd wɪð ɪt. ðə dɑɡz fɑloʊd, əntɪl ðeɪ leɪ flæɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, tʌŋz lɑlɪŋ fɹəm ðɛɹ maʊðz. θɹi teɪlz wæɡd.

Slowly Elyas lowered his hand, and the pitch of his whistle lowered with it. The dogs followed, until they lay flat on the ground, tongues lolling from their mouths. Three tails wagged.

"si," ɛlaɪəs sɛd, wɔkɪŋ tə ðə dɑɡz. "ðɛɹz noʊ nid fəɹ wɛpənz." ðə mæstəfs lɪkt ɪz hænz, ən i skɹætʃt ðɛɹ bɹɔd hɛdz ən fɑndəl ðɛɹ ɪɹz. "ðeɪ lʊk minɝ ðən ðeɪ ɑɹ. ðeɪ mɛn tə fɹaɪɾən əs ɔf, ən ðeɪ wʊdn əv bɪɾən ənlɛs wi tʃɹaɪd tə ɡoʊ ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz. ɛniweɪ, ðɛɹz noʊ wɝi ʌv ðæt, naʊ. wi kən meɪk ðə nɛks θɪkɪt bɪfɔɹ fʊl dɑɹk."

"See," Elyas said, walking to the dogs. "There's no need for weapons." The mastiffs licked his hands, and he scratched their broad heads and fondled their ears. "They look meaner than they are. They meant to frighten us off, and they wouldn't have bitten unless we tried to go into the trees. Anyway, there's no worry of that, now. We can make the next thicket before full dark."

wən pɛɹɪn lʊkt əɾ ɛɡwin, hɝ maʊθ wɑz hæŋɪŋ oʊpən. hi ʃʌɾ ɪz oʊn maʊθ wɪð ə klɪk ə tiθ.

When Perrin looked at Egwene, her mouth was hanging open. He shut his own mouth with a click of teeth.

stɪl pæɾɪŋ ðə dɑɡz, ɛlaɪəs stʌɾid ðə stæn ə tʃɹiz. "ðɛɹəl bi tuætɑn hɪɹ. ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl." ðeɪ stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm blæŋkli, ən i æɾəd, "tɪŋkɝz."

Still patting the dogs, Elyas studied the stand of trees. "There'll be Tuatha'an here. The Traveling People." They stared at him blankly, and he added, "Tinkers."

"tɪŋkɝz?" pɛɹɪn ɪkskleɪmd. "aɪv ɔlweɪz wɑntəd tə si ðə tɪŋkɝz. ðeɪ kæmp əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ fɹəm tɛɹən fɛɹi səmtaɪmz, bʌt ðeɪ doʊn kʌm daʊn ɪndə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, əz fɑɹ əz aɪ noʊ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ nɑt."

"Tinkers?" Perrin exclaimed. "I've always wanted to see the Tinkers. They camp across the river from Taren Ferry sometimes, but they don't come down into the Two Rivers, as far as I know. I don't know why not."

ɛɡwin snɪft. "pɹɑbli kəz ðə tɛɹən fɛɹi foʊk ɑɹ əz ɡɹeɪt θivz əz ðə tɪŋkɝz. ðeɪd noʊ daʊɾ ɛn ʌp stilɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ blaɪnd. mæstɝ ɛlaɪəs, ɪf ðəɹ ɹɪli ɑɹ tɪŋkɝz kloʊz baɪ, ʃʊdnt wi ɡoʊ ɑn? wi doʊnt wɑn bɛlə stoʊlən, ən . . . wɛl, wi də nɑɾ əv mʌtʃ ɛls, bʌɾ ɛvɹibɑɾi noʊz tɪŋkɝz wɪl stil ɛniθɪŋ."

Egwene sniffed. "Probably because the Taren Ferry folk are as great thieves as the Tinkers. They'd no doubt end up stealing each other blind. Master Elyas, if there really are Tinkers close by, shouldn't we go on? We don't want Bela stolen, and . . . well, we do not have much else, but everybody knows Tinkers will steal anything."

"ɪnkluɾɪŋ ɪnfəns?" ɛlaɪəs æsk dʒɹaɪli. "kɪdnæp tʃɪlʒɹən, ən ɔl ðæt?" hi spæt, ən ʃi blʌʃt. ðoʊz stɔɹiz əbaʊt beɪbiz wɝ toʊl səmtaɪmz, bʌt moʊst ɔfən baɪ sɛn bui əɹ wʌn ə ðə kɑplɪnz əɹ kɔŋɡɝz. ði ʌðɝ teɪlz, ɛvɹibɑɾi nu. "ðə tɪŋkɝz meɪk mi sɪk səmtaɪmz, bʌt ðeɪ doʊn stil ɛni mɔɹ ðən moʊs foʊks. ə ɡʊd bɪt lɛs ðən səm aɪ noʊ."

"Including infants?" Elyas asked dryly. "Kidnap children, and all that?" He spat, and she blushed. Those stories about babies were told sometimes, but most often by Cenn Buie or one of the Coplins or Congars. The other tales, everybody knew. "The Tinkers make me sick sometimes, but they don't steal any more than most folks. A good bit less than some I know."

"ɪt wɪl bi ɡɛɾɪŋ dɑɹk sun, ɛlaɪəs," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wi hæv tə kæmp sʌmwɛɹ. waɪ nɑt wɪð ðɛm, ɪf ðəl əv ʌs?" mɪstʃɹəs luhən hæɾ ə tɪŋkɝ-mɛndɪd pɑt ðət ʃi kleɪmd wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən nu. mæstɝ luhən wɑz nɑt tu hæpi əbaʊɾ ɪz waɪfs pɹeɪz ə ðə tɪŋkɝ wɝk, bʌt pɛɹɪn wɑntəd tə si haʊ ɪt wɑz dʌn. jɛt ðəɹ wɑz ə ɹɪlʌktəns əbaʊɾ ɛlaɪəs ðəɾ i dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd. "ɪz ðəɹ səm ɹizən wi ʃʊdnt?"

"It will be getting dark soon, Elyas," Perrin said. "We have to camp somewhere. Why not with them, if they'll have us?" Mistress Luhhan had a Tinker-mended pot that she claimed was better than new. Master Luhhan was not too happy about his wife's praise of the Tinker work, but Perrin wanted to see how it was done. Yet there was a reluctance about Elyas that he did not understand. "Is there some reason we shouldn't?"

ɛlaɪəs ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, bʌt ðə ɹɪlʌktəns wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, ɪn ðə sɛɾ ə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən ðə taɪtnəs ə hɪz maʊθ. "meɪ əz wɛl. dʒʌs doʊn peɪ ɛni maɪn tə wʌt ðeɪ seɪ. lɑɾ ə fulɪʃnəs. moʊs taɪmz ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl də θɪŋz ɛni wɪtʃ weɪ, bʌt ðɛɹz taɪmz ðeɪ sɛɾ ə stɔɹ baɪ fɔɹmæləɾi, soʊ jə də wʌɾ aɪ du. ən kip jəɹ sikɹəts. noʊ nid tə tɛl ðə wɝld ɛvɹiθɪŋ."

Elyas shook his head, but the reluctance was still there, in the set of his shoulders and the tightness of his mouth. "May as well. Just don't pay any mind to what they say. Lot of foolishness. Most times the Traveling People do things any which way, but there's times they set a store by formality, so you do what I do. And keep your secrets. No need to tell the world everything."

ðə dɑɡz tʃɹeɪld əlɔŋ bɪsaɪd ðɛm, wæɡɪŋ ðɛɹ teɪlz, əz ɛlaɪəs lɛd ðə weɪ ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz. pɛɹɪn fɛl ðə wʊlvz sloʊ, ən nu ðeɪ wəd nɑɾ ɛntɝ. ðeɪ wɝ nɑɾ əfɹeɪɾ ə ðə dɑɡz - ðeɪ wɝ kəntɛmptʃuəs ə dɑɡz, hu hæd ɡɪvən ʌp fɹiɾəm tə slip baɪ ə faɪɝ - bʌt pipəl ðeɪ əvɔɪɾəd.

The dogs trailed along beside them, wagging their tails, as Elyas led the way into the trees. Perrin felt the wolves slow, and knew they would not enter. They were not afraid of the dogs - they were contemptuous of dogs, who had given up freedom to sleep by a fire - but people they avoided.

ɛlaɪəs wɔkt ʃʊɹli, əz ɪf i nu ðə weɪ, ən nɪɹ ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə stæn ðə tɪŋkɝz' wæɡənz əpɪɹd, skæɾɝd əmʌŋ ði oʊk ən æʃ.

Elyas walked surely, as if he knew the way, and near the center of the stand the Tinkers' wagons appeared, scattered among the oak and ash.

laɪk ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls ɪn ɛmənz fild, pɛɹɪn hæd hɝɾ ə ɡʊd dil əbaʊt ðə tɪŋkɝz ivən ɪf i hæd nɛvɝ sin ɛni, ən ðə kæmp wɑz dʒʌst wʌɾ i ɪkspɛktəd. ðɛɹ wæɡənz wɝ smɔl haʊsəz ɑn wilz, tɔl wʊɾən bɑksəz lækɝɾ ən peɪntəɾ ɪn bɹaɪt kʌlɝz, ɹɛdz ən bluz ən jɛloʊz ən ɡɹinz ən səm hjuz tə wɪtʃ i kəd nɑt pʊɾ ə neɪm. ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ əbaʊt wɝk ðət wɑz dɪsəpɔɪntɪŋli ɛvɹideɪ, kʊkɪŋ, soʊɪŋ, tɛndɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən, mɛndɪŋ hɑɹnəs, bʌt ðɛɹ kloʊðz wɝ ivən mɔɹ kʌlɝfəl ðən ðə wæɡənz - ən simɪŋli tʃoʊzən ət ɹændəm; səmtaɪmz koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz, əɹ dʒɹɛs ən ʃɔl, wɛn təɡɛðɝ ɪn ə weɪ ðət hɝɾ ɪz aɪz. ðeɪ lʊk laɪk bʌɾɝflaɪz ɪn ə fild ʌv waɪldflaʊɹz.

Like everyone else in Emond's Field, Perrin had heard a good deal about the Tinkers even if he had never seen any, and the camp was just what he expected. Their wagons were small houses on wheels, tall wooden boxes lacquered and painted in bright colors, reds and blues and yellows and greens and some hues to which he could not put a name. The Traveling People were going about work that was disappointingly everyday, cooking, sewing, tending children, mending harness, but their clothes were even more colorful than the wagons - and seemingly chosen at random; sometimes coat and breeches, or dress and shawl, went together in a way that hurt his eyes. They looked like butterflies in a field of wildflowers.

fɔɹ əɹ faɪv mɛn ɪn dɪfɹən pleɪsəz ɝaʊn ðə kæmp pleɪd fɪɾəlz ən fluts, ən ə fju pipəl dæns laɪk ɹeɪnboʊ-hjud hʌmɪŋbɝdz. tʃɪlʒɹən ən dɑɡz ɹæn pleɪɪŋ əmʌŋ ðə kʊkfaɪɝz. ðə dɑɡz wɝ mæstəfs dʒʌs laɪk ðoʊz ðət hæd kənfɹʌntəd ðə tʃɹævəlɝz, bʌt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən tʌɡd ət ðɛɹ ɪɹz ən teɪlz ən klaɪmd ɑn ðɛɹ bæks, ən ðə mæsɪv dɑɡz æksɛptɪɾ ɪɾ ɔl plɑtʃədli. ðə θɹi wɪð ɛlaɪəs, tʌŋz hæŋɪŋ aʊt, lʊkt ʌp ət ðə bɪɹɾəd mæn əz ɪf i wɝ ðɛɹ bɛs fɹɛnd. pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ðeɪ wɝ stɪl bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə ɹitʃ ə mænz θɹoʊt waɪl bɛɹli ɡɛɾɪŋ ðɛɹ fɹʌn fiɾ ɔf ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

Four or five men in different places around the camp played fiddles and flutes, and a few people danced like rainbow-hued hummingbirds. Children and dogs ran playing among the cookfires. The dogs were mastiffs just like those that had confronted the travelers, but the children tugged at their ears and tails and climbed on their backs, and the massive dogs accepted it all placidly. The three with Elyas, tongues hanging out, looked up at the bearded man as if he were their best friend. Perrin shook his head. They were still big enough to reach a man's throat while barely getting their front feet off the ground.

əbɹʌpli ðə mjuzɪk stɑpt, ən i ɹilaɪzd ɔl ðə tɪŋkɝz wɝ lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm ən ɪz kəmpænjənz. ivən ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ən dɑɡz stʊd stɪl ən wɑtʃt, wɛɹəli, əz ɪf ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə flaɪt.

Abruptly the music stopped, and he realized all the Tinkers were looking at him and his companions. Even the children and dogs stood still and watched, warily, as if on the point of flight.

fəɹ ə moʊmən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saʊn əɾ ɔl, ðən ə wɪɹi mæn, ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹɾ ən ʃɔɹt, stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ən baʊd ɡɹeɪvli tə ɛlaɪəs. hi wɔɹ ə haɪ-kɑlɝd ɹɛd koʊt, ən bæɡi, bɹaɪt ɡɹin tʃɹaʊzɝz tʌkt ɪndə ni buts. "ju ɑɹ wɛlkəm tə əɹ faɪɝz. dʒju noʊ ðə sɔŋ?"

For a moment there was no sound at all, then a wiry man, gray-haired and short, stepped forward and bowed gravely to Elyas. He wore a high-collared red coat, and baggy, bright green trousers tucked into knee boots. "You are welcome to our fires. Do you know the song?"

ɛlaɪəs baʊɾ ɪn ðə seɪm weɪ, boʊθ hænz pɹɛs tə hɪz tʃɛst. "jɔɹ wɛlkəm wɔɹmz maɪ spɪɹət, mɑɾi, əz jəɹ faɪɝz wɔɹm ðə flɛʃ, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt noʊ ðə sɔŋ."

Elyas bowed in the same way, both hands pressed to his chest. "Your welcome warms my spirit, Mahdi, as your fires warm the flesh, but I do not know the song."

"ðɛn wi sik stɪl," ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn ɪntoʊnd. "æz ɪt wɑz, soʊ ʃæl ɪt bi, ɪf wi bʌt ɹɪmɛmbɝ, sik, ən faɪnd." hi swɛpt ən ɑɹm təwɔɹd ðə faɪɝz wɪð ə smaɪl, ən ɪz vɔɪs tʊk ɑn ə tʃɪɹfəl laɪtnəs. "ðə mil ɪz ɔlmoʊst ɹɛɾi. dʒɔɪn ʌs, pliz."

"Then we seek still," the gray-haired man intoned. "As it was, so shall it be, if we but remember, seek, and find." He swept an arm toward the fires with a smile, and his voice took on a cheerful lightness. "The meal is almost ready. Join us, please."

əz ɪf ðət hæd bɪn ə sɪɡnəl ðə mjuzɪk spɹæŋ ʌp əɡɛn, ən ðə tʃɪlʒɹən tʊk ʌp ðɛɹ læftɝ ən ɹæn wɪð ðə dɑɡz. ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə kæmp wɛn bæk tə wʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn duɪŋ dʒʌst əz ðoʊ ðə nukʌmɝz wɝ lɔŋ-æksɛptɪd fɹɛnz.

As if that had been a signal the music sprang up again, and the children took up their laughter and ran with the dogs. Everyone in the camp went back to what they had been doing just as though the newcomers were long-accepted friends.

ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðoʊ, ən lʊkt əɾ ɛlaɪəs. "jɔɹ . . . ʌðɝ fɹɛnz? ðəl steɪ əweɪ? ðeɪ fɹaɪɾən ðə pʊɹ dɑɡz soʊ."

The gray-haired man hesitated, though, and looked at Elyas. "Your . . . other friends? They will stay away? They frighten the poor dogs so."

"ðeɪl steɪ əweɪ, ɹən." ɛlaɪəsəz hɛdʃeɪk hæɾ ə tʌtʃ ə skɔɹn. "ju ʃəd noʊ ðət baɪ naʊ."

"They'll stay away, Raen." Elyas's headshake had a touch of scorn. "You should know that by now."

ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn spɹɛɾ ɪz hænz əz ɪf tə seɪ nʌθɪŋ wɑz ɛvɝ sɝɾən. əz i tɝn tə liɾ əm ɪndə ðə kæmp, ɛɡwin dɪsmaʊntɪɾ ən muv kloʊs tə ɛlaɪəs. "ju tu ɑɹ fɹɛnz?" ə smaɪlɪŋ tɪŋkɝ əpɪɹd tə teɪk bɛlə; ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ðə ɹeɪnz ʌp ɹɪlʌktənli, æftɝ ə ɹaɪ snɔɹt fɹəm ɛlaɪəs.

The gray-haired man spread his hands as if to say nothing was ever certain. As he turned to lead them into the camp, Egwene dismounted and moved close to Elyas. "You two are friends?" A smiling Tinker appeared to take Bela; Egwene gave the reins up reluctantly, after a wry snort from Elyas.

"wi noʊ itʃ ʌðɝ," ðə fɝ-klæd mæn ɹɪplaɪd kɝtli.

"We know each other," the fur-clad man replied curtly.

"hɪz neɪm ɪz mɑɾi?" pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"His name is Mahdi?" Perrin said.

ɛlaɪəs ɡɹaʊl sʌmθɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. "hɪz neɪmz ɹən. mɑɾiz ɪz taɪɾəl. sikɝ. hiz ðə liɾɝ ə ðɪs bænd. jə kən kɔl ɪm sikɝ ɪf ði ʌðɝ saʊnz ɑd. hi woʊn maɪnd."

Elyas growled something under his breath. "His name's Raen. Mahdi's his title. Seeker. He's the leader of this band. You can call him Seeker if the other sounds odd. He won't mind."

"wʌt wɑz ðəɾ əbaʊɾ ə sɔŋ?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"What was that about a song?" Egwene asked.

"ðæts waɪ ðeɪ tʃɹævəl," ɛlaɪəs sɛd, "ɔɹ soʊ ðeɪ seɪ. ðəɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ə sɔŋ. ðæts wʌt ðə mɑɾi siks. ðeɪ seɪ ðeɪ lɔst ɪt dʊɹɪŋ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ən ɪf ðeɪ kən faɪn ɪɾ əɡɛn, ðə pɛɹədaɪs ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz wɪl ɹɪtɝn." hi ɹæn ɪz aɪ ɝaʊn ðə kæmp ən snɔɹɾɪd. "ðeɪ doʊn ivən noʊ wʌt ðə sɔŋ ɪz; ðeɪ kleɪm ðəl noʊ ɪt wən ðeɪ faɪn ɪt. ðeɪ doʊnt noʊ haʊ ɪts səpoʊz tə bɹɪŋ pɛɹədaɪs, iðɝ, bʌt ðeɪv bɪn lʊkɪŋ nɪɹ tə θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz, ɛvɝ sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ. aɪ ɪkspɛk ðəl bi lʊkɪŋ əntɪl ðə wil stɑps tɝnɪŋ."

"That's why they travel," Elyas said, "or so they say. They're looking for a song. That's what the Mahdi seeks. They say they lost it during the Breaking of the World, and if they can find it again, the paradise of the Age of Legends will return." He ran his eye around the camp and snorted. "They don't even know what the song is; they claim they'll know it when they find it. They don't know how it's supposed to bring paradise, either, but they've been looking near to three thousand years, ever since the Breaking. I expect they'll be looking until the Wheel stops turning."

ðeɪ ɹitʃt ɹənz faɪɝ, ðɛn, ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə kæmp. ðə sikɝz wæɡən wɑz jɛloʊ tʃɹɪmd ɪn ɹɛd, ən ðə spoʊks ʌv ɪts tɔl, ɹɛd-ɹɪmd wilz ɔltɝneɪɾəd ɹɛɾ ən jɛloʊ. ə plʌmp wʊmən, əz ɡɹeɪ əz ɹən bʌt smuð-tʃik stɪl, keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə wæɡən ən pɔzd ɑn ðə stɛps əɾ ɪts bæk ɛnd, stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ ə blu-fɹɪnd ʃɔl ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. hɝ blaʊs wɑz jɛloʊ ən əɹ skɝt ɹɛd, boʊθ bɹaɪt. ðə kɑmbəneɪʃən meɪd pɛɹɪn blɪŋk, ən ɛɡwin meɪɾ ə stʃɹæŋɡəl saʊnd.

They reached Raen's fire, then, in the middle of the camp. The Seeker's wagon was yellow trimmed in red, and the spokes of its tall, red-rimmed wheels alternated red and yellow. A plump woman, as gray as Raen but smooth-cheeked still, came out of the wagon and paused on the steps at its back end, straightening a blue-fringed shawl on her shoulders. Her blouse was yellow and her skirt red, both bright. The combination made Perrin blink, and Egwene made a strangled sound.

wən ʃi sɔ ðə pipəl fɑloʊɪŋ ɹən, ðə wʊmən keɪm daʊn wɪð ə wɛlkəmɪŋ smaɪl. ʃi wɑz ilə, ɹənz waɪf, ə hɛd tɔlɝ ðən əɹ hʌzbənd, ən ʃi sun meɪd pɛɹɪn fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊt ðə kʌlɝz ə hɝ kloʊðz. ʃi hæɾ ə mʌðɝlaɪnəs ðət ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ə mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ ən hæɾ ɪm filɪŋ wɛlkəm fɹəm əɹ fɝst smaɪl.

When she saw the people following Raen, the woman came down with a welcoming smile. She was Ila, Raen's wife, a head taller than her husband, and she soon made Perrin forget about the colors of her clothes. She had a motherliness that reminded him of Mistress al'Vere and had him feeling welcome from her first smile.

ilə ɡɹiɾəd ɛlaɪəs əz ən oʊld əkweɪntəns, bʌt wɪð ə dɪstəns ðət sim tə peɪn ɹən. ɛlaɪəs ɡeɪv əɹ ə dʒɹaɪ ɡɹɪn ən ə nɑd. pɛɹɪn ən ɛɡwin ɪntʃɹədus ðɛmsɛlvz, ən ʃi klæsp ðɛɹ hænz ɪn boʊθ ə hɝz wɪð mʌtʃ mɔɹ wɔɹmθ ðən ʃi hæd ʃoʊn ɛlaɪəs, ivən hʌɡɪŋ ɛɡwin.

Ila greeted Elyas as an old acquaintance, but with a distance that seemed to pain Raen. Elyas gave her a dry grin and a nod. Perrin and Egwene introduced themselves, and she clasped their hands in both of hers with much more warmth than she had shown Elyas, even hugging Egwene.

"waɪ, jəɹ lʌvli, tʃaɪld," ʃi sɛd, kʌpɪŋ ɛɡwinz tʃɪn ən smaɪlɪŋ. "æn tʃɪl tə ðə boʊn, tu, aɪ ɪkspɛkt. jə sɪt kloʊs tə ðə faɪɝ, ɛɡwin. ɔl ə jə sɪt. sʌpɝ ɪz ɔlmoʊst ɹɛɾi."

"Why, you're lovely, child," she said, cupping Egwene's chin and smiling. "And chilled to the bone, too, I expect. You sit close to the fire, Egwene. All of you sit. Supper is almost ready."

fɔlən lɔɡz hæd bɪn pʊld ɝaʊn ðə faɪɝ fəɹ sɪɾɪŋ. ɛlaɪəs ɹəfjuzd ivən ðət kənsɛʃən tə sɪvəlɪzeɪʃən. hi laʊnʒd ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɪnstɛd. aɪɝn tʃɹaɪpɑdz hɛl tu smɔl kɛɾəlz oʊvɝ ðə fleɪmz, ən ən ʌvən ɹɛstəɾ ɪn ði ɛdʒ ə ðə koʊlz. ilə tɛndəd ðɛm.

Fallen logs had been pulled around the fire for sitting. Elyas refused even that concession to civilization. He lounged on the ground, instead. Iron tripods held two small kettles over the flames, and an oven rested in the edge of the coals. Ila tended them.

əz pɛɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ teɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ pleɪsəz, ə slɛndɝ jʌŋ mæn wɛɹɪŋ ɡɹin stʃɹaɪps stʃɹoʊld ʌp tə ðə faɪɝ. hi ɡeɪv ɹən ə hʌɡ ən ilə ə kɪs, ən ɹæn ə kul aɪ oʊvɝ ɛlaɪəs ən ði ɛmənz fildɝz. hi wɑz əbaʊt ðə seɪm eɪdʒ əz pɛɹɪn, ən i muvd əz ɪf i wɝ əbaʊt tə bɪɡɪn dænsɪŋ wɪð ɪz nɛkst stɛp.

As Perrin and the others were taking their places, a slender young man wearing green stripes strolled up to the fire. He gave Raen a hug and Ila a kiss, and ran a cool eye over Elyas and the Emond's Fielders. He was about the same age as Perrin, and he moved as if he were about to begin dancing with his next step.

"wɛl, ɛɹæm" - ilə smaɪl fɑnli - "ju hæv dɪsaɪɾɪd tə it wɪð jəɹ oʊld ɡɹændpɛɹəns fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ, hæv ju?" hɝ smaɪl slɪɾ oʊvɝ tə ɛɡwin əz ʃi bɛn tə stɝ ə kɛɾəl hæŋɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə kʊkfaɪɝ. "aɪ wʌndɝ waɪ?"

"Well, Aram" - Ila smiled fondly - "you have decided to eat with your old grandparents for a change, have you?" Her smile slid over to Egwene as she bent to stir a kettle hanging over the cookfire. "I wonder why?"

ɛɹæm sɛɾəld tə ən izi kɹaʊtʃ wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz kɹɔst ɑn ɪz niz, əkɹɔs ðə faɪɝ fɹəm ɛɡwin. "aɪ æm ɛɹæm," hi toʊld əɹ ɪn ə loʊ, kɑnfəɾənt vɔɪs. hi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ simd əwɛɹ ðəɾ ɛniwʌn wɑz ðəɹ ɪksɛp hɝ. "aɪ hæv weɪɾəd fəɹ ðə fɝst ɹoʊz ə spɹɪŋ, ən naʊ aɪ faɪn ɪɾ ət maɪ ɡɹændfɑðɝz faɪɝ."

Aram settled to an easy crouch with his arms crossed on his knees, across the fire from Egwene. "I am Aram," he told her in a low, confident voice. He no longer seemed aware that anyone was there except her. "I have waited for the first rose of spring, and now I find it at my grandfather's fire."

pɛɹɪn weɪɾəd fəɹ ɛɡwin tə snɪkɝ, ðən sɔ ðət ʃi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ bæk əɾ ɛɹæm. hi lʊkt ət ðə jʌŋ tɪŋkɝ əɡɛn. ɛɹæm hæd mɔɹ ðən ɪz ʃɛɹ ʌv ɡʊd lʊks, hi ədmɪɾəd. æftɝ ə mɪnət pɛɹɪn nu hu ðə fɛloʊ ɹimaɪndəɾ ɪm ʌv. wɪl ælsin, hu hæɾ ɔl ðə ɡɝlz stɛɹɪŋ ən wɪspɝɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk wɛnɛvɝ i keɪm ʌp fɹəm dɛvən ɹaɪd tə ɛmənz fild. wɪl kɔɹɾɪd ɛvɹi ɡɝl ɪn saɪt, ən mænədʒ tə kənvɪns ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðɛm ðəɾ i wɑz dʒʌs biɪŋ pəlaɪt tə ɔl ði ʌðɝz.

Perrin waited for Egwene to snicker, then saw that she was staring back at Aram. He looked at the young Tinker again. Aram had more than his share of good looks, he admitted. After a minute Perrin knew who the fellow reminded him of. Wil al'Seen, who had all the girls staring and whispering behind his back whenever he came up from Deven Ride to Emond's Field. Wil courted every girl in sight, and managed to convince every one of them that he was just being polite to all the others.

"ðoʊz dɑɡz ə jʊɹz," pɛɹɪn sɛd laʊdli, ən ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, "lʊk əz bɪɡ əz bɛɹz. aɪm sɝpɹaɪz jə lɛt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən pleɪ wɪð ðɛm."

"Those dogs of yours," Perrin said loudly, and Egwene gave a start, "look as big as bears. I'm surprised you let the children play with them."

ɛɹæmz smaɪl slɪpt, bʌt wən i lʊkt ət pɛɹɪn ɪt keɪm bæk əɡɛn, ivən mɔɹ ʃʊɹ ðən bɪfɔɹ. "ðeɪ wɪl nɑt hɑɹm ju. ðeɪ meɪk ə ʃoʊ tə fɹaɪɾən əweɪ deɪnʒɝ, ən wɔɹn ʌs, bʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹeɪn əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif."

Aram's smile slipped, but when he looked at Perrin it came back again, even more sure than before. "They will not harm you. They make a show to frighten away danger, and warn us, but they are trained according to the Way of the Leaf."

"ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif?" ɛɡwin sɛd. "wʌɾ ɪz ðæt?"

"The Way of the Leaf?" Egwene said. "What is that?"

ɛɹæm dʒɛstʃɝd tə ðə tʃɹiz, hɪz aɪz fæsən ɪntɛnli ɑn hɝz. "ðə lif lɪvz ɪts əpɔɪntəd taɪm, ən dʌz nɑt stʃɹʌɡəl əɡɛns ðə wɪn ðət kæɹiz ɪɾ əweɪ. ðə lif dʌz noʊ hɑɹm, ən faɪnəli fɔlz tə nɝɪʃ nu livz. soʊ ɪt ʃəd bi wɪð ɔl mɛn. ən wɪmən." ɛɡwin stɛɹd bæk ət hɪm, ə feɪn blʌʃ ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪn əɹ tʃiks.

Aram gestured to the trees, his eyes fastened intently on hers. "The leaf lives its appointed time, and does not struggle against the wind that carries it away. The leaf does no harm, and finally falls to nourish new leaves. So it should be with all men. And women." Egwene stared back at him, a faint blush rising in her cheeks.

"bʌt wʌt dʌz ðət min?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. ɛɹæm ɡeɪv ɪm ən ɪɹəteɪɾəd ɡlæns, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɹən u ænsɝd.

"But what does that mean?" Perrin said. Aram gave him an irritated glance, but it was Raen who answered.

"ɪt minz ðət noʊ mæn ʃəd hɑɹm ənʌðɝ fəɹ ɛni ɹizən wʌtsoʊɛvɝ." ðə sikɝz aɪz flɪkɝd tə ɛlaɪəs. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ ɪkskjus fəɹ vaɪələns. nʌn. nɑɾ ɛvɝ."

"It means that no man should harm another for any reason whatsoever." The Seeker's eyes flickered to Elyas. "There is no excuse for violence. None. Not ever."

"wʌɾ ɪf sʌmbɑɾi ətæks ju?" pɛɹɪn ɪnsɪstəd. "wʌɾ ɪf sʌmbɑɾi hɪts ju, əɹ tʃɹaɪz tə ɹɑb ju, əɹ kɪl ju?"

"What if somebody attacks you?" Perrin insisted. "What if somebody hits you, or tries to rob you, or kill you?"

ɹən saɪd, ə peɪʃən saɪ, əz ɪf pɛɹɪn wɑz dʒʌs nɑt siɪŋ wʌt wɑz soʊ klɪɹ tə hɪm. "ɪf ə mæn hɪt mi, aɪ wəɾ æsk ɪm waɪ hi wɑntəd tə də sətʃ ə θɪŋ. ɪf i stɪl wɑntəd tə hɪt mi, aɪ wəd ɹʌn əweɪ, əz aɪ wəɾ ɪf i wɑntəd tə ɹɑb əɹ kɪl mi. mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðəɾ aɪ lɛɾ ɪm teɪk wʌɾ i wɑntəd, ivən maɪ laɪf, ðən ðəɾ aɪ ʃəd də vaɪələns. ən aɪ wəd hoʊp ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt hɑɹm tu ɡɹeɪtli."

Raen sighed, a patient sigh, as if Perrin was just not seeing what was so clear to him. "If a man hit me, I would ask him why he wanted to do such a thing. If he still wanted to hit me, I would run away, as I would if he wanted to rob or kill me. Much better that I let him take what he wanted, even my life, than that I should do violence. And I would hope that he was not harmed too greatly."

"bʌt jə sɛd jə wʊdn hɝt hɪm," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "aɪ wəd nɑt, bʌt vaɪələns hɑɹmz ðə wʌn u dʌz ɪɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ðə wʌn u ɹəsivz ɪt." pɛɹɪn lʊk daʊtfəl. "ju kəd kʌt daʊn ə tʃɹi wɪð jəɹ æks," ɹən sɛd. "ði æks dʌz vaɪələns tə ðə tʃɹi, ən ɪskeɪps ənhɑɹmd. ɪz ðət haʊ jə si ɪt? wʊɾ ɪz sɑf kəmpɛɹd tə stil, bʌt ðə ʃɑɹp stil ɪz dʌld əz ɪt tʃɑps, ən ðə sæp ə ðə tʃɹi wɪl ɹʌst ən pɪɾ ɪt. ðə maɪɾi æks dʌz vaɪələns tə ðə hɛlpləs tʃɹi, ən ɪz hɑɹm baɪ ɪt. soʊ ɪts wɪð mɛn, ðoʊ ðə hɑɹm ɪz ɪn ðə spɪɹət."

"But you said you wouldn't hurt him," Perrin said. "I would not, but violence harms the one who does it as much as the one who receives it." Perrin looked doubtful. "You could cut down a tree with your axe," Raen said. "The axe does violence to the tree, and escapes unharmed. Is that how you see it? Wood is soft compared to steel, but the sharp steel is dulled as it chops, and the sap of the tree will rust and pit it. The mighty axe does violence to the helpless tree, and is harmed by it. So it is with men, though the harm is in the spirit."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"ɪnʌf," ɛlaɪəs ɡɹaʊld, kʌɾɪŋ pɛɹɪn ɔf. "ɹən, ɪts bæɾ ɪnʌf jə tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kənvɝt vɪlədʒ jʌŋɡəlɪŋz tə ðət nɑnsɛns - ɪt ɡɛts jə ɪn tʃɹʌbəl ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwɛɹ jə ɡoʊ, dʌzn ɪt? - bʌɾ aɪ dɪdn bɹɪŋ ðɪs lɑt hɪɹ fəɹ jə tə wɝk ɑn ðɛm. liv oʊvɝ."

"Enough," Elyas growled, cutting Perrin off. "Raen, it's bad enough you trying to convert village younglings to that nonsense - it gets you in trouble almost everywhere you go, doesn't it? - but I didn't bring this lot here for you to work on them. Leave over."

"æn liv əm tə ju?" ilə sɛd, ɡɹaɪndɪŋ ɝbz bɪtwin əɹ pɑmz ən lɛɾɪŋ əm tʃɹɪkəl ɪndə wʌn ə ðə kɛɾəlz. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz kɑm, bʌɾ əɹ hænz ɹʌb ði ɝbz fjʊɹiəsli. "wɪl jə titʃ əm jəɹ weɪ, tə kɪl əɹ daɪ? wɪl jə lɛɾ əm tə ðə feɪt jə sik fəɹ jɝsɛlf, daɪɪŋ əloʊn wɪð oʊnli ðə ɹeɪvənz ən jəɹ . . . jəɹ fɹɛnz tə skwɑbəl oʊvɝ jəɹ bɑɾi?"

"And leave them to you?" Ila said, grinding herbs between her palms and letting them trickle into one of the kettles. Her voice was calm, but her hands rubbed the herbs furiously. "Will you teach them your way, to kill or die? Will you lead them to the fate you seek for yourself, dying alone with only the ravens and your . . . your friends to squabble over your body?"

"bi ət pis, ilə," ɹən sɛd dʒɛnli, əz ɪf i hæd hɝd ðɪs ɔl ən mɔɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz. "hi hæz bɪn wɛlkəm tə əɹ faɪɝ, maɪ waɪf."

"Be at peace, Ila," Raen said gently, as if he had heard this all and more a hundred times. "He has been welcomed to our fire, my wife."

ilə səbsaɪɾɪd, bʌt pɛɹɪn noʊɾəst ðət ʃi meɪd noʊ əpɑlədʒi. ɪnstɛd ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɛlaɪəs ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd sædli, ðən dʌstɪɾ əɹ hænz ən bɪɡæn teɪkɪŋ spunz ən pɑɾɝi boʊlz fɹəm ə ɹɛd tʃɛst ɑn ðə saɪɾ ə ðə wæɡən.

Ila subsided, but Perrin noticed that she made no apology. Instead she looked at Elyas and shook her head sadly, then dusted her hands and began taking spoons and pottery bowls from a red chest on the side of the wagon.

ɹən tɝn bæk tə ɛlaɪəs. "maɪ oʊl fɹɛnd, haʊ mɛni taɪmz mʌst aɪ tɛl jə ðət wi də nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə kənvɝɾ ɛniwʌn. wən vɪlədʒ pipəl ɑɹ kjʊɹiəs əbaʊɾ əɹ weɪz, wi ænsɝ ðɛɹ kwɛstʃənz. ɪts moʊst ɔfən ðə jʌŋ u æsk, tʃɹu, ən səmtaɪmz wʌn ə ðɛm wɪl kʌm wɪð əs wən wi dʒɝni ɑn, bʌɾ ɪts ə ðɛɹ oʊn fɹi wɪl."

Raen turned back to Elyas. "My old friend, how many times must I tell you that we do not try to convert anyone. When village people are curious about our ways, we answer their questions. It is most often the young who ask, true, and sometimes one of them will come with us when we journey on, but it is of their own free will."

"ju tʃɹaɪ tɛlɪŋ ðət tə səm fɑɹm waɪf huz dʒʌs faʊn aʊɾ əɹ sʌn əɹ dɔɾɝ əz ɹʌn ɔf wɪð jə tɪŋkɝz," ɛlaɪəs sɛd ɹaɪli. "ðæts waɪ ðə bɪɡɝ taʊnz woʊn ivən lɛt jə kæmp nɪɹbaɪ. vɪlədʒəz pʊɾ ʌp wɪð jə fəɹ jəɹ mɛndɪŋ θɪŋz, bʌt ðə sɪɾiz doʊnt niɾ ɪt, ən ðeɪ doʊn laɪk jə tɔkɪŋ ðɛɹ jʌŋ foʊks ɪndə ɹʌnɪŋ ɔf."

"You try telling that to some farm wife who's just found out her son or daughter has run off with you Tinkers," Elyas said wryly. "That's why the bigger towns won't even let you camp nearby. Villages put up with you for your mending things, but the cities don't need it, and they don't like you talking their young folks into running off."

"aɪ wəd nɑt noʊ wʌt ðə sɪɾiz əlaʊ." ɹənz peɪʃəns simd ɪnɪɡzɔstəbəl. hi sɝɾənli dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə bi ɡɛɾɪŋ æŋɡɹi əɾ ɔl. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ɔlweɪz vaɪələn mɛn ɪn sɪɾiz. ɪn ɛni keɪs, aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ðə sɔŋ kəd bi faʊn ɪn ə sɪɾi."

"I would not know what the cities allow." Raen's patience seemed inexhaustible. He certainly did not appear to be getting angry at all. "There are always violent men in cities. In any case, I do not think the song could be found in a city."

"aɪ doʊn min tə əfɛn ju, sikɝ," pɛɹɪn sɛd sloʊli, "bʌt. . . . wɛl, aɪ doʊn lʊk fəɹ vaɪələns. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk aɪv ivən ɹɛsəld ɛnibəɾi ɪn jɪɹz, ɪksɛp fəɹ fistdeɪ ɡeɪmz. bʌɾ ɪf sʌmbɑɾi hɪt mi, aɪd hɪɾ ɪm bæk. ɪf aɪ dɪdnt, aɪ wəd dʒʌs bi ɛnkɝɪdʒɪŋ ɪm tə θɪŋk i kəd hɪt mi wɛnɛvɝ i wɑntəd tə. səm pipəl θɪŋk ðeɪ kən teɪk ædvæntɪdʒ ʌv ʌðɝz, ən ɪf jə doʊn lɛɾ əm noʊ ðeɪ kænt, ðəl dʒʌst ɡoʊ ɝaʊn bʊliɪŋ ɛnibəɾi wikɝ ðən ðeɪ ɑɹ."

"I don't mean to offend you, Seeker," Perrin said slowly, "but. . . . Well, I don't look for violence. I don't think I've even wrestled anybody in years, except for feastday games. But if somebody hit me, I'd hit him back. If I didn't, I would just be encouraging him to think he could hit me whenever he wanted to. Some people think they can take advantage of others, and if you don't let them know they can't, they'll just go around bullying anybody weaker than they are."

"sʌm pipəl," ɛɹæm sɛd wɪð ə hɛvi sædnəs, "kæn nɛvɝ oʊvɝkʌm ðɛɹ bæzɝ ɪnstɪŋks." hi sɛɾ ɪt wɪð ə lʊk ət pɛɹɪn ðət meɪɾ ɪt klɪɹ i wɑz nɑt tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt ðə bʊliz pɛɹɪn spoʊk ʌv.

"Some people," Aram said with a heavy sadness, "can never overcome their baser instincts." He said it with a look at Perrin that made it clear he was not talking about the bullies Perrin spoke of.

"aɪl bɛt jə ɡɛt tə ɹʌn əweɪ ə lɑt," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ən ðə jʌŋ tɪŋkɝz feɪs taɪɾənd ɪn ə weɪ ðət hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif.

"I'll bet you get to run away a lot," Perrin said, and the young Tinker's face tightened in a way that had nothing to do with the Way of the Leaf.

"aɪ θɪŋk ɪts ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ," ɛɡwin sɛd, ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət pɛɹɪn, "tə mit sʌmwʌn u dʌzn bɪliv ɪz mʌsəlz kən sɑlv ɛvɹi pɹɑbləm."

"I think it is interesting," Egwene said, glaring at Perrin, "to meet someone who doesn't believe his muscles can solve every problem."

ɛɹæmz ɡʊd spɪɹəts ɹɪtɝnd, ən i stʊd, ɔfɝɪŋ əɹ ɪz hænz wɪð ə smaɪl. "lɛt mi ʃoʊ jə əɹ kæmp. ðəɹ ɪz dænsɪŋ."

Aram's good spirits returned, and he stood, offering her his hands with a smile. "Let me show you our camp. There is dancing."

"aɪ wəd laɪk ðæt." ʃi smaɪl bæk.

"I would like that." She smiled back.

ilə stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm teɪkɪŋ loʊvz ə bɹɛd fɹəm ðə smɔl aɪɝn ʌvən. "bʌt sʌpɝ ɪz ɹɛɾi, ɛɹæm."

Ila straightened from taking loaves of bread from the small iron oven. "But supper is ready, Aram."

"aɪl it wɪð mʌðɝ," ɛɹæm sɛɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ əz i dʒɹu ɛɡwin əweɪ fɹəm ðə wæɡən baɪ hɝ hænd. "wi wɪl boʊθ it wɪð mʌðɝ." hi flæʃt ə tʃɹaɪʌmfən smaɪl ət pɛɹɪn. ɛɡwin wɑz læfɪŋ əz ðeɪ ɹæn.

"I'll eat with mother," Aram said over his shoulder as he drew Egwene away from the wagon by her hand. "We will both eat with mother." He flashed a triumphant smile at Perrin. Egwene was laughing as they ran.

pɛɹɪn ɡɑt tə hɪz fit, ðən stɑpt. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz ɪf ʃi kəd kʌm tə ɛni hɑɹm, nɑɾ ɪf ðə kæmp fɑloʊd ðɪs weɪ ʌv ðə lif əz ɹən sɛd. lʊkɪŋ ət ɹən ən ilə, boʊθ stɛɹɪŋ dɪdʒɛktɪdli æftɝ ðɛɹ ɡɹændsʌn, hi sɛd, "aɪm sɑɹi. aɪm ə ɡɛst, ən aɪ ʃʊdn əv - "

Perrin got to his feet, then stopped. It was not as if she could come to any harm, not if the camp followed this Way of the Leaf as Raen said. Looking at Raen and Ila, both staring dejectedly after their grandson, he said, "I'm sorry. I am a guest, and I shouldn't have - "

"doʊn bi fulɪʃ," ilə sɛd suðɪŋli. "ɪt wɑz ɪz fɔlt, nɑt jʊɹz. sɪt daʊn ən it."

"Don't be foolish," Ila said soothingly. "It was his fault, not yours. Sit down and eat."

"ɛɹæm ɪz ə tʃɹʌbəl jʌŋ mæn," ɹən æɾəd sædli. "hi ɪz ə ɡʊd bɔɪ, bʌt səmtaɪmz aɪ θɪŋk i faɪnz ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif ə hɑɹd weɪ. səm du, aɪ fɪɹ. pliz. maɪ faɪɝ ɪz jʊɹz. pliz?"

"Aram is a troubled young man," Raen added sadly. "He is a good boy, but sometimes I think he finds the Way of the Leaf a hard way. Some do, I fear. Please. My fire is yours. Please?"

pɛɹɪn sæt bæk daʊn sloʊli, stɪl filɪŋ ɑkwɝd. "wʌt hæpənz tə sʌmbɑɾi hu kæn fɑloʊ ðə weɪ?" hi æskt. "eɪ tɪŋkɝ, aɪ min."

Perrin sat back down slowly, still feeling awkward. "What happens to somebody who can't follow the Way?" he asked. "A Tinker, I mean."

ɹən ən ilə ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə wɝid lʊk, ən ɹən sɛd, "ðeɪ liv ʌs. ðə lɔst ɡoʊ tə lɪv ɪn ðə vɪlədʒəz."

Raen and Ila exchanged a worried look, and Raen said, "They leave us. The Lost go to live in the villages."

ilə stɛɹɾ ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən əɹ ɡɹændsʌn hæd ɡɔn. "ðə lɔs kænɑt bi hæpi." ʃi saɪd, bʌɾ əɹ feɪs wɑz plæsəɾ əɡɛn wən ʃi hændəɾ aʊt ðə boʊlz ən spunz.

Ila stared in the direction her grandson had gone. "The Lost cannot be happy." She sighed, but her face was placid again when she handed out the bowls and spoons.

pɛɹɪn stɛɹɾ ət ðə ɡɹaʊnd, wɪʃɪŋ i hæd nɑɾ æskt, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɔɹ tɔk waɪl ilə fɪl ðɛɹ boʊlz wɪð ə θɪk vɛdʒtəbəl stu ən hændəɾ aʊt θɪk slaɪsəz ə hɝ kɹʌsti bɹɛd, nɔɹ waɪl ðeɪ eɪt. ðə stu wɑz dɪlɪʃəs, ən pɛɹɪn fɪnɪʃt θɹi boʊlz bɪfɔɹ i stɑpt. ɛlaɪəs, hi noʊɾəd wɪð ə ɡɹɪn, ɛmptid fɔɹ.

Perrin stared at the ground, wishing he had not asked, and there was no more talk while Ila filled their bowls with a thick vegetable stew and handed out thick slices of her crusty bread, nor while they ate. The stew was delicious, and Perrin finished three bowls before he stopped. Elyas, he noted with a grin, emptied four.

æftɝ ðə mil ɹən fɪld ɪz paɪp, ən ɛlaɪəs pɹədust ɪz oʊn ən stʌft ɪt fɹəm ɹənz ɔɪlskɪn paʊtʃ. wən ðə laɪɾɪŋ ən tæmpɪŋ ən ɹɪlaɪɾɪŋ wɝ dʌn, ðeɪ sɛɾəld bæk ɪn saɪləns. ilə tʊk aʊɾ ə bʌndəl ə nɪɾɪŋ. ðə sʌn wɑz oʊnli ə bleɪz ə ɹɛɾ əbʌv ðə tʃɹitɑps tə ðə wɛst. ðə kæmp hæd sɛɾəld ɪn fəɹ ðə naɪt, bʌt ðə bʌsəl dɪd nɑt sloʊ, oʊnli tʃeɪnʒd. ðə mjuzɪʃənz u hæd bɪn pleɪɪŋ wən ðeɪ ɛntɝd ðə kæmp hæd bɪn ɹipleɪs baɪ ʌðɝz, ən ivən mɔɹ pipəl ðən bɪfɔɹ dænst ɪn ðə laɪɾ ə ðə faɪɝz, ðɛɹ ʃædoʊz lipɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wæɡənz. sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə kæmp ə kɔɹəs ə meɪl vɔɪsəz ɹoʊz. pɛɹɪn slɪd daʊn ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə lɔɡ ən sun fɛl hɪmsɛlf doʊzɪŋ.

After the meal Raen filled his pipe, and Elyas produced his own and stuffed it from Raen's oilskin pouch. When the lighting and tamping and relighting were done, they settled back in silence. Ila took out a bundle of knitting. The sun was only a blaze of red above the treetops to the west. The camp had settled in for the night, but the bustle did not slow, only changed. The musicians who had been playing when they entered the camp had been replaced by others, and even more people than before danced in the light of the fires, their shadows leaping against the wagons. Somewhere in the camp a chorus of male voices rose. Perrin slid down in front of the log and soon felt himself dozing.

æftɝ ə taɪm ɹən sɛd, "hæv jə vɪzəɾəd ɛni ʌv ðə tuætɑn, ɛlaɪəs, sɪns jə wɝ wɪð əs læst spɹɪŋ?"

After a time Raen said, "Have you visited any of the Tuatha'an, Elyas, since you were with us last spring?"

pɛɹɪnz aɪz dʒɹɪftəɾ oʊpən ən hæf ʃʌɾ əɡɛn.

Perrin's eyes drifted open and half shut again.

"noʊ," ɛlaɪəs ɹɪplaɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz paɪpɛstəm. "aɪ doʊn laɪk biɪŋ ɝaʊn tu mɛni pipəl ət wʌns."

"No," Elyas replied around his pipestem. "I don't like being around too many people at once."

ɹən tʃʌkəld. "ɪspɛʃli pipəl u lɪv ɪn ə weɪ soʊ ɑpəzət tə jəɹ oʊn, ɛ? noʊ, maɪ oʊl fɹɛnd, doʊnt wɝi. aɪ ɡeɪv ʌp jɪɹz əɡoʊ hoʊpɪŋ jə wəd kʌm tə ðə weɪ. bʌɾ aɪ hæv hɝɾ ə stɔɹi sɪns læst wi mɛt, ən ɪf juv nɑt hɝɾ ɪt jɛt, ɪt maɪɾ ɪntʃɹəs ju. ɪɾ ɪntʃɹəsts mi, ən aɪ hæv hɝɾ ɪɾ əɡɛn ən əɡɛn, ɛvɹi taɪm wi miɾ ʌðɝz ə ðə pipəl."

Raen chuckled. "Especially people who live in a way so opposite to your own, eh? No, my old friend, don't worry. I gave up years ago hoping you would come to the Way. But I have heard a story since last we met, and if you have not heard it yet, it might interest you. It interests me, and I have heard it again and again, every time we meet others of the People."

"aɪl lɪsən."

"I'll listen."

"ɪt bɪɡɪnz ɪn ðə spɹɪŋ tu jɪɹz əɡoʊ, wɪð ə bæn ə ðə pipəl u wɝ kɹɔsɪŋ ðə weɪs baɪ ðə nɔɹðɝn ɹut."

"It begins in the spring two years ago, with a band of the People who were crossing the Waste by the northern route."

pɛɹɪnz aɪz ʃɑɾ oʊpən. "ðə weɪst? ði il weɪst? ðeɪ wɝ kɹɔsɪŋ ði il weɪst?"

Perrin's eyes shot open. "The Waste? The Aiel Waste? They were crossing the Aiel Waste?"

"sʌm pipəl kən ɛntɝ ðə weɪst wɪθaʊt biɪŋ bɑðɝd," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. "ɡlimən. pɛdlɝz, ɪf ðəɹ ɑnəst. ðə tuætɑn kɹɔs ðə weɪst ɔl ðə taɪm. mɝtʃəns fɹəm kɛɹhin juz tə, bɪfɔɹ ðə tʃɹi, ən ði il wɔɹ."

"Some people can enter the Waste without being bothered," Elyas said. "Gleemen. Peddlers, if they're honest. The Tuatha'an cross the Waste all the time. Merchants from Cairhien used to, before the Tree, and the Aiel War."

"ði ilmɛn əvɔɪɾ ʌs," ɹən sɛd sædli, "ðoʊ mɛni ʌv əs əv tʃɹaɪd tə spik wɪð ðɛm. ðeɪ wɑtʃ əs fɹəm ə dɪstəns, bʌt ðəl nɑt kʌm nɪɹ ʌs, nɔɹ lɛɾ əs kʌm nɪɹ ðɛm. səmtaɪmz aɪ wɝi ðət ðeɪ maɪt noʊ ðə sɔŋ, ðoʊ aɪ səpoʊz ɪɾ ɪzən laɪkli. əmʌŋ il, mɛn də nɑt sɪŋ, jə noʊ. ɪzən ðət stʃɹeɪnʒ? fɹəm ðə taɪm ən il bɔɪ bɪkʌmz ə mæn hɪl nɑt sɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt bæɾəl tʃæns, əɹ ðɛɹ dɝdʒ fəɹ ðə sleɪn. aɪ hæv hɝɾ əm sɪŋɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ dɛd, ən oʊvɝ ðoʊz ðeɪv kɪld. ðət sɔŋ ɪz wʌn tə meɪk ðə stoʊnz wip." ilə, lɪsnɪŋ, nɑɾəd əɡɹimən oʊvɝ əɹ nɪɾɪŋ.

"The Aielmen avoid us," Raen said sadly, "though many of us have tried to speak with them. They watch us from a distance, but they will not come near us, nor let us come near them. Sometimes I worry that they might know the song, though I suppose it isn't likely. Among Aiel, men do not sing, you know. Isn't that strange? From the time an Aiel boy becomes a man he will not sing anything but battle chants, or their dirge for the slain. I have heard them singing over their dead, and over those they have killed. That song is one to make the stones weep." Ila, listening, nodded agreement over her knitting.

pɛɹɪn dɪd səm kwɪk ɹiθɪŋkɪŋ. hi hæd θɔt ðə tɪŋkɝz mʌs bi əfɹeɪɾ ɔl ðə taɪm, wɪð ɔl ðɪs tɔk ə ɹʌnɪŋ əweɪ, bʌt noʊ wʌn u wɑz əfɹeɪd wəɾ ivən θɪŋk ə kɹɔsɪŋ ði il weɪst. fɹəm wʌɾ i hæd hɝd, noʊ wʌn u wɑz seɪn wəd tʃɹaɪ kɹɔsɪŋ ðə weɪst.

Perrin did some quick rethinking. He had thought the Tinkers must be afraid all the time, with all this talk of running away, but no one who was afraid would even think of crossing the Aiel Waste. From what he had heard, no one who was sane would try crossing the Waste.

"ɪf ðɪs ɪz səm stɔɹi əbaʊɾ ə sɔŋ," ɛlaɪəs bɪɡæn, bʌt ɹən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

"If this is some story about a song," Elyas began, but Raen shook his head.

"noʊ, maɪ oʊl fɹɛnd, nɑɾ ə sɔŋ. aɪm nɑt ʃʊɹ aɪ noʊ wʌɾ ɪts əbaʊt." hi tɝn ɪz ətɛnʃən tə pɛɹɪn. "jʌŋ il ɔfən tʃɹævəl ɪndə ðə blaɪt. səm ə ðə jʌŋ mɛn ɡoʊ əloʊn, θɪŋkɪŋ fəɹ səm ɹizən ðət ðeɪv bɪn kɔl tə kɪl ðə dɑɹk wʌn. moʊst ɡoʊ ɪn smɔl ɡɹups. tə hʌn tʃɹɑləks." ɹən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sædli, ən wən i wɛn ɑn ɪz vɔɪs wɑz hɛvi. "tu jɪɹz əɡoʊ ə bæn ə ðə pipəl kɹɔsɪŋ ðə weɪst əbaʊɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz saʊθ ə ðə blaɪt faʊnd wʌn ə ðiz ɡɹups."

"No, my old friend, not a song. I am not sure I know what it is about." He turned his attention to Perrin. "Young Aiel often travel into the Blight. Some of the young men go alone, thinking for some reason that they have been called to kill the Dark One. Most go in small groups. To hunt Trollocs." Raen shook his head sadly, and when he went on his voice was heavy. "Two years ago a band of the People crossing the Waste about a hundred miles south of the Blight found one of these groups."

"jʌŋ wɪmən," ilə pʊɾ ɪn, əz sɑɹoʊfəl əz əɹ hʌzbənd. "lɪɾəl mɔɹ ðən ɡɝlz."

"Young women," Ila put in, as sorrowful as her husband. "Little more than girls."

pɛɹɪn meɪɾ ə sɝpɹaɪz saʊnd, ən ɛlaɪəs ɡɹɪn əɾ ɪm ɹaɪli.

Perrin made a surprised sound, and Elyas grinned at him wryly.

"il ɡɝlz doʊn əv tə tɛn haʊs ən kʊk ɪf ðeɪ doʊnt wɑn tə, bɔɪ. ðə wʌnz u wɑnə bi wɔɹiɝz, ɪnstɛd, dʒɔɪn wʌn ə ðə wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz, fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ, ðə meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ, ən faɪt ɹaɪɾ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə mɛn."

"Aiel girls don't have to tend house and cook if they don't want to, boy. The ones who want to be warriors, instead, join one of the warrior societies, Far Dareis Mai, the Maidens of the Spear, and fight right alongside the men."

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. ɛlaɪəs tʃʌkəld əɾ ɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən.

Perrin shook his head. Elyas chuckled at his expression.

ɹən tʊk ʌp ðə stɔɹi əɡɛn, dɪsteɪst ən pɝplɛksəɾi mɪŋɡəld ɪn ɪz vɔɪs. "ðə jʌŋ wɪmən wɝ ɔl dɛɾ ɪksɛpt wʌn, ən ʃi wɑz daɪɪŋ. ʃi kɹɔl tə ðə wæɡənz. ɪt wɑz klɪɹ ʃi nu ðeɪ wɝ tuætɑn. hɝ loʊθɪŋ aʊtweɪɾ əɹ peɪn, bʌt ʃi hæɾ ə mɛsədʒ soʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə hɝ ðət ʃi mʌs pæs ɪɾ ɑn tə sʌmwʌn, ivən ʌs, bɪfɔɹ ʃi daɪd. mɛn wɛn tə si ɪf ðeɪ kəd hɛlp ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz - ðəɹ wɑz ə tʃɹeɪl ə hɝ blʌd tə fɑloʊ - bʌɾ ɔl wɝ dɛd, ən soʊ wɝ θɹi taɪmz ðɛɹ nʌmbɝ ɪn tʃɹɑləks."

Raen took up the story again, distaste and perplexity mingled in his voice. "The young women were all dead except one, and she was dying. She crawled to the wagons. It was clear she knew they were Tuatha'an. Her loathing outweighed her pain, but she had a message so important to her that she must pass it on to someone, even us, before she died. Men went to see if they could help any of the others - there was a trail of her blood to follow - but all were dead, and so were three times their number in Trollocs."

ɛlaɪəs sæɾ ʌp, hɪz paɪp ɔlmoʊs fɔlɪŋ fɹəm bɪtwin ɪz tiθ. "ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz ɪndə ðə weɪst? ɪmpɑsəbəl! jɛvɪk ɹ, ðæts wʌt tʃɹɑləks kɔl ðə weɪst. ðə daɪɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd. ðeɪ wʊdnt ɡoʊ ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz ɪndə ðə weɪst ɪf ɔl ðə mɹdʒɹɑl ɪn ðə blaɪt wɝ dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ðɛm."

Elyas sat up, his pipe almost falling from between his teeth. "A hundred miles into the Waste? Impossible! Djevik K'Shar, that's what Trollocs call the Waste. The Dying Ground. They wouldn't go a hundred miles into the Waste if all the Myrddraal in the Blight were driving them."

"ju noʊ ən ɑfəl lɑɾ əbaʊt tʃɹɑləks, ɛlaɪəs," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"You know an awful lot about Trollocs, Elyas," Perrin said.

"ɡoʊ ɑn wɪð jəɹ stɔɹi," ɛlaɪəs toʊld ɹən ɡɹʌflaɪ.

"Go on with your story," Elyas told Raen gruffly.

"fɹʌm tʃɹoʊfiz ði il kæɹid, ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs ðeɪ wɝ kʌmɪŋ bæk fɹəm ðə blaɪt. ðə tʃɹɑləks hæd fɑloʊd, bʌt baɪ ðə tʃɹæks oʊnli ə fju lɪv tə ɹɪtɝn æftɝ kɪlɪŋ ði il. əz fəɹ ðə ɡɝl, ʃi wəd nɑt lɛɾ ɛniwʌn tʌtʃ hɝ, ivən tə tɛn əɹ wunz. bʌt ʃi siz ðə sikɝ ə ðət bæn baɪ hɪz koʊt, ən ðɪs ɪz wʌt ʃi sɛd, wɝd fəɹ wɝd. 'lifblaɪɾɝ minz tə blaɪn ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld, lɔst wʌn. hi minz tə sleɪ ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpənt. wɔɹn ðə pipəl, lɔst wʌn. saɪtbɝnɝ kʌmz. tɛl əm tə stæn ɹɛɾi fəɹ i hu kʌmz wɪð ðə dɔn. tɛl ðɛm. . . .' ən ðən ʃi daɪd. lifblaɪɾɝ ən saɪtbɝnɝ," ɹən æɾəd tə pɛɹɪn, "ɑɹ il neɪmz fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstæn ənʌðɝ wɝɾ ʌv ɪt. jɛt ʃi θɔɾ ɪɾ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɪnʌf tə əpɹoʊtʃ ðoʊz ʃi ɑbviəsli dɪspaɪzd, tə pæs ɪɾ ɑn wɪð əɹ læs bɹɛθ. bʌt tə hu? wəɹ aʊɝsɛlvz, ðə pipəl, bʌɾ aɪ hɑɹdli θɪŋk ʃi mɛn ɪt fəɹ ʌs. ði il? ðeɪ wəd nɑt lɛɾ əs tɛl əm ɪf wi tʃɹaɪd." hi saɪd hɛvəli. "ʃi kɔld əs ðə lɔst. aɪ nɛvɝ nu bɪfɔɹ haʊ mʌtʃ ðeɪ loʊð ʌs." ilə sɛɾ əɹ nɪɾɪŋ ɪn əɹ læp ən tʌtʃt ɪz hɛd dʒɛnli.

"From trophies the Aiel carried, it was obvious they were coming back from the Blight. The Trollocs had followed, but by the tracks only a few lived to return after killing the Aiel. As for the girl, she would not let anyone touch her, even to tend her wounds. But she seized the Seeker of that band by his coat, and this is what she said, word for word. 'Leafblighter means to blind the Eye of the World, Lost One. He means to slay the Great Serpent. Warn the People, Lost One. Sightburner comes. Tell them to stand ready for He Who Comes With the Dawn. Tell them. . . .' And then she died. Leafblighter and Sightburner," Raen added to Perrin, "are Aiel names for the Dark One, but I don't understand another word of it. Yet she thought it important enough to approach those she obviously despised, to pass it on with her last breath. But to who? We are ourselves, the People, but I hardly think she meant it for us. The Aiel? They would not let us tell them if we tried." He sighed heavily. "She called us the Lost. I never knew before how much they loathe us." Ila set her knitting in her lap and touched his head gently.

"sʌmθɪŋ ðeɪ lɝn ɪn ðə blaɪt," ɛlaɪəs mjuzd. "bʌt nʌn ʌv ɪt meɪks sɛns. sleɪ ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpənt? kɪl taɪm ɪtsɛlf? ən blaɪn ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld? əz wɛl seɪ hiz gɑnə stɑɹv ə ɹɑk. meɪbi ʃi wɑz bæbəlɪŋ, ɹən. wundəd, daɪɪŋ, ʃi cʊɾə lɔst əɹ ɡɹɪp ɑn wʌt wɑz ɹil. meɪbi ʃi dɪdn ivən noʊ hu ðoʊz tuætɑn wɝ."

"Something they learned in the Blight," Elyas mused. "But none of it makes sense. Slay the Great Serpent? Kill time itself? And blind the Eye of the World? As well say he's going to starve a rock. Maybe she was babbling, Raen. Wounded, dying, she could have lost her grip on what was real. Maybe she didn't even know who those Tuatha'an were."

"ʃi nu wʌt ʃi wɑz seɪɪŋ, ən tə hum ʃi wɑz seɪɪŋ ɪt. sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə hɝ ðən əɹ oʊn laɪf, ən wi kænɑɾ ivən ʌndɝstæn ɪt. wən aɪ sɔ jə wɔkɪŋ ɪndə əɹ kæmp, aɪ θɔt pɝhæps wi wəd faɪn ði ænsɝ ət læst, sɪns jə wɝ" - ɛlaɪəs meɪɾ ə kwɪk moʊʃən wɪð ɪz hænd, ən ɹən tʃeɪnʒd wʌɾ i hæd bɪn gɑnə seɪ - "ɑɹ ə fɹɛnd, ən noʊ mɛni stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz."

"She knew what she was saying, and to whom she was saying it. Something more important to her than her own life, and we cannot even understand it. When I saw you walking into our camp, I thought perhaps we would find the answer at last, since you were" - Elyas made a quick motion with his hand, and Raen changed what he had been going to say - "are a friend, and know many strange things."

"nɑɾ əbaʊt ðɪs," ɛlaɪəs sɛɾ ɪn ə toʊn ðət pʊɾ ən ɛn tə tɔk. ðə saɪləns ɝaʊn ðə kæmpfaɪɝ wɑz bɹoʊkən oʊnli baɪ ðə mjuzɪk ən læftɝ dʒɹɪftɪŋ fɹəm ʌðɝ pɑɹts ə ðə naɪt-ʃɹaʊɾɪd kæmp.

"Not about this," Elyas said in a tone that put an end to talk. The silence around the campfire was broken only by the music and laughter drifting from other parts of the night-shrouded camp.

laɪɪŋ wɪð ɪz ʃoʊldɝz pɹɑpt ɑn wʌn ə ðə lɔɡz ɝaʊn ðə faɪɝ, pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd pʌzəlɪŋ aʊt ði il wʊmənz mɛsədʒ, bʌɾ ɪt meɪd noʊ mɔɹ sɛns tə hɪm ðən ɪt hæd tə ɹən əɹ ɛlaɪəs. ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld. ðət hæd bɪn ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz, mɔɹ ðən wʌns, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðoʊz dʒɹimz. ɛlaɪəs, naʊ. ðəɹ wɑz ə kwɛstʃən ðəɹ i wəd laɪk ænsɝd. wʌt hæd ɹən bɪn əbaʊt tə seɪ əbaʊt ðə bɪɹɾəd mæn, ən waɪ hæɾ ɛlaɪəs kʌɾ ɪm ɔf? hi hæd noʊ lʌk wɪð ðæt, iðɝ. hi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪmædʒən wʌɾ il ɡɝlz wɝ laɪk - ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə ðə blaɪt, wɛɹ oʊnli wɔɹɾɝz wɛn ðəɾ i hæɾ ɛvɝ hɝd; faɪɾɪŋ tʃɹɑləks - wən i hɝɾ ɛɡwin kʌmɪŋ bæk, sɪŋɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf.

Lying with his shoulders propped on one of the logs around the fire, Perrin tried puzzling out the Aiel woman's message, but it made no more sense to him than it had to Raen or Elyas. The Eye of the World. That had been in his dreams, more than once, but he did not want to think about those dreams. Elyas, now. There was a question there he would like answered. What had Raen been about to say about the bearded man, and why had Elyas cut him off? He had no luck with that, either. He was trying to imagine what Aiel girls were like - going into the Blight, where only Warders went that he had ever heard; fighting Trollocs - when he heard Egwene coming back, singing to herself.

skɹæmbəlɪŋ tə hɪz fit, hi wɛn tə miɾ əɹ ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə faɪɹlaɪt. ʃi stɑpt ʃɔɹt, lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm wɪð əɹ hɛd tɪltəd tə wʌn saɪd. ɪn ðə dɑɹk i kəd nɑt ɹɛɾ əɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən.

Scrambling to his feet, he went to meet her at the edge of the firelight. She stopped short, looking at him with her head tilted to one side. In the dark he could not read her expression.

"juv bɪn ɡɔn ə lɔŋ taɪm," hi sɛd. "dɪd juv fʌn?"

"You've been gone a long time," he said. "Did you have fun?"

"wi eɪt wɪð ɪz mʌðɝ," ʃi ænsɝd. "æn ðən wi dænst . . . ən læft. ɪt simz laɪk fɝɛvɝ sɪns aɪ dænst."

"We ate with his mother," she answered. "And then we danced . . . and laughed. It seems like forever since I danced."

"hi ɹimaɪnz mi ʌv wɪl ælsin. jə ɔlweɪz hæd sɛns ɪnʌf nɑt tə lɛt wɪl pʊt jə ɪn ɪz pɑkət."

"He reminds me of Wil al'Seen. You always had sense enough not to let Wil put you in his pocket."

"ɛɹæm ɪz ə dʒɛntəl bɔɪ hu ɪz fʌn tə bi wɪð," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə taɪt vɔɪs. "hi meɪks mi læf."

"Aram is a gentle boy who is fun to be with," she said in a tight voice. "He makes me laugh."

pɛɹɪn saɪd. "aɪm sɑɹi. aɪm ɡlæd jə hæd fʌn dænsɪŋ."

Perrin sighed. "I'm sorry. I'm glad you had fun dancing."

əbɹʌpli ʃi flʌŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɪm, wipɪŋ ɑn ɪz ʃɝt. ɔkwɝdli hi pæɾəd əɹ hɛɹ. ɹænd wəd noʊ wʌt tə du, hi θɔt. ɹænd hæɾ ən izi weɪ wɪð ɡɝlz. nɑt laɪk hɪm, hu nɛvɝ nu wʌt tə də əɹ seɪ. "aɪ toʊl jə aɪm sɑɹi, ɛɡwin. aɪ ɹɪli æm ɡlæd jə hæd fʌn dænsɪŋ. ɹɪli."

Abruptly she flung her arms around him, weeping on his shirt. Awkwardly he patted her hair. Rand would know what to do, he thought. Rand had an easy way with girls. Not like him, who never knew what to do or say. "I told you I'm sorry, Egwene. I really am glad you had fun dancing. Really."

"tɛl mi ðəɹ əlaɪv," ʃi mʌmbəld ɪndə hɪz tʃɛst.

"Tell me they're alive," she mumbled into his chest.

"wʌt?"

"What?"

ʃi pʊʃt bæk tə ɑɹmz lɛŋθ, hɝ hænz ɑn ɪz ɑɹmz, ən lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪm ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs. "ɹæn ən mæt. ði ʌðɝz. tɛl mi ðeɪ ɑɹ əlaɪv."

She pushed back to arm's length, her hands on his arms, and looked up at him in the darkness. "Rand and Mat. The others. Tell me they are alive."

hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən lʊkt ɝaʊn ənsɝteɪnli. "ðeɪ ɑɹ əlaɪv," hi sɛd faɪnəli.

He took a deep breath and looked around uncertainly. "They are alive," he said finally.

"ɡʊd." ʃi skɹʌbd əɾ əɹ tʃiks wɪð kwɪk fɪŋɡɝz. "ðæɾ ɪz wʌɾ aɪ wɑntəd tə hɪɹ. ɡʊd naɪt, pɛɹɪn. slip wɛl." stændɪŋ ɑn tɪptoʊ, ʃi bɹʌʃt ə kɪs əkɹɔs ɪz tʃik ən hɝid pæst ɪm bɪfɔɹ i kəd spik.

"Good." She scrubbed at her cheeks with quick fingers. "That is what I wanted to hear. Good night, Perrin. Sleep well." Standing on tiptoe, she brushed a kiss across his cheek and hurried past him before he could speak.

hi tɝn tə wɑtʃ hɝ. ilə ɹoʊz tə mit hɝ, ən ðə tu wɪmən wɛn ɪndə ðə wæɡən tɔkɪŋ kwaɪətli. ɹænd maɪɾ ʌndɝstæn ɪt, hi θɔt, bʌɾ aɪ doʊnt.

He turned to watch her. Ila rose to meet her, and the two women went into the wagon talking quietly. Rand might understand it, he thought, but I don't.

ɪn ðə dɪstənt naɪt ðə wʊlvz haʊl ðə fɝs θɪn slɪvɝ ə ðə nu mun təwɔɹd ðə hɝaɪzən, ən i ʃɪvɝd. təmɑɹoʊ wəd bi taɪm ɪnʌf tə wɝi əbaʊt ðə wʊlvz əɡɛn. hi wɑz ɹɔŋ. ðeɪ wɝ weɪɾɪŋ tə ɡɹiɾ ɪm ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz.

In the distant night the wolves howled the first thin sliver of the new moon toward the horizon, and he shivered. Tomorrow would be time enough to worry about the wolves again. He was wrong. They were waiting to greet him in his dreams.


tʃæptɝ twɛntisɪks


CHAPTER 26

waɪtbɹɪdʒ


Whitebridge

ðə læst ənstɛɾi noʊɾ ʌv wʌt hæd bɪn bɛɹli ɹɛkəɡnaɪzəbəl əz "ðə wɪn ðət ʃeɪks ðə wɪloʊ" feɪɾəd mɝsɪfəli əweɪ, ən mæt loʊɝd tɑmz ɡoʊld-ænd-sɪlvɝ-tʃeɪs flut. ɹænd tʊk ɪz hænz fɹəm ɪz ɪɹz. ə seɪlɝ kɔɪlɪŋ ə laɪn ɑn ðə dɛk nɪɹbaɪ hivd ə laʊd saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif. fəɹ ə moʊmən ði oʊnli saʊnz wɝ ðə wɔɾɝ slæpɪŋ əɡɛns ðə hʌl, ðə ɹɪðmɪk kɹik ə ði ɔɹz, ən naʊ ən əɡɛn ðə hʌm ə ɹɪɡɪŋ stʃɹʌm baɪ ðə wɪnd. ðə wɪn blu dɛɾ ɑn tə ðə spɹeɪz baʊ, ən ðə jusləs seɪlz wɝ fɝld.

The last unsteady note of what had been barely recognizable as "The Wind That Shakes the Willow" faded mercifully away, and Mat lowered Thom's gold-and-silver-chased flute. Rand took his hands from his ears. A sailor coiling a line on the deck nearby heaved a loud sigh of relief. For a moment the only sounds were the water slapping against the hull, the rhythmic creak of the oars, and now and again the hum of rigging strummed by the wind. The wind blew dead on to the Spray's bow, and the useless sails were furled.

"aɪ səpoʊz aɪ ʃəd θæŋk ju," tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn mʌɾɝd faɪnəli, "fɔɹ titʃɪŋ mi haʊ tʃɹu ði oʊl seɪɪŋ ɪz. titʃ ɪm haʊ jə wɪl, ə pɪɡ wɪl nɛvɝ pleɪ ðə flut." ðə seɪlɝ bɝst aʊt læfɪŋ, ən mæt ɹeɪz ðə fluɾ əz ɪf tə θɹoʊ ɪɾ ət hɪm. dɛfli, tɑm snæɡd ði ɪnstʃɹəmən fɹəm mæts fɪst ən fɪɾəd ɪɾ ɪndə ɪts hɑɹd lɛðɝ keɪs. "aɪ θɔɾ ɔl jə ʃɛpɝdz waɪld əweɪ ðə taɪm wɪð ðə flɑk pleɪɪŋ ðə paɪps əɹ ðə flut. ðət wɪl ʃoʊ mi tə tʃɹʌst wʌɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ fɝsthænd."

"I suppose I should thank you," Thom Merrilin muttered finally, "for teaching me how true the old saying is. Teach him how you will, a pig will never play the flute." The sailor burst out laughing, and Mat raised the flute as if to throw it at him. Deftly, Thom snagged the instrument from Mat's fist and fitted it into its hard leather case. "I thought all you shepherds whiled away the time with the flock playing the pipes or the flute. That will show me to trust what I don't know firsthand."

"ɹænz ðə ʃɛpɝd," mæt ɡɹʌmbəld. "hi pleɪz ðə paɪps, nɑt mi."

"Rand's the shepherd," Mat grumbled. "He plays the pipes, not me."

"jɛs, wɛl, hi dʌz əv ə lɪɾəl æptətud. pɝhæps wi hæd bɛɾɝ wɝk ɑn dʒʌɡəlɪŋ, bɔɪ. ət lis jə ʃoʊ səm tælən fəɹ ðæt."

"Yes, well, he does have a little aptitude. Perhaps we had better work on juggling, boy. At least you show some talent for that."

"tɑm," ɹænd sɛd, "aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ jəɹ tʃɹaɪɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd." hi ɡlænst ət ðə seɪlɝ ən loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs. "æftɝ ɔl, wi ɑɹən ɹɪli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə bɪkʌm ɡlimən. ɪts oʊnli sʌmθɪŋ tə haɪd bɪhaɪn əntɪl wi faɪn mɔɪɹeɪn ən ði ʌðɝz."

"Thom," Rand said, "I don't know why you're trying so hard." He glanced at the sailor and lowered his voice. "After all, we aren't really trying to become gleemen. It's only something to hide behind until we find Moiraine and the others."

tɑm tʌɡd əɾ ən ɛn ə hɪz mʌstæʃ ən sim tə bi stʌɾiɪŋ ðə smuð, dɑɹk bɹaʊn lɛðɝ ə ðə flut keɪs ɑn ɪz niz. "wʌɾ ɪf jə doʊn faɪn ðɛm, bɔɪ? ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ tə seɪ ðəɹ ivən stɪl əlaɪv."

Thom tugged at an end of his mustache and seemed to be studying the smooth, dark brown leather of the flute case on his knees. "What if you don't find them, boy? There's nothing to say they're even still alive."

"ðeɪɹ əlaɪv," ɹænd sɛd fɝmli. hi tɝn tə mæt fəɹ səpɔɹt, bʌt mæts aɪbɹaʊz wɝ pɪntʃt daʊn ɑn ɪz noʊz, ən ɪz maʊθ wɑz ə θɪn laɪn, ən ɪz aɪz wɝ fɪkst ɑn ðə dɛk. "wɛl, spik ʌp," ɹænd toʊl hɪm. "ju kæn bi ðət mæɾ oʊvɝ nɑt biɪŋ eɪbəl tə pleɪ ðə flut. aɪ kæn iðɝ, nɑt vɛɹi wɛl. jə nɛvɝ wɑntəd tə pleɪ ðə flut bɪfɔɹ."

"They're alive," Rand said firmly. He turned to Mat for support, but Mat's eyebrows were pinched down on his nose, and his mouth was a thin line, and his eyes were fixed on the deck. "Well, speak up," Rand told him. "You can't be that mad over not being able to play the flute. I can't either, not very well. You never wanted to play the flute before."

mæt lʊkt ʌp, stɪl fɹaʊnɪŋ. "wʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ dɛd?" hi sɛd sɔfli. "wi hæv tə æksɛp fæks, ɹaɪt?"

Mat looked up, still frowning. "What if they are dead?" he said softly. "We have to accept facts, right?"

ət ðət moʊmən ðə lʊkaʊɾ ɪn ðə baʊ sæŋ aʊt, "waɪtbɹɪdʒ! waɪtbɹɪdʒ əhɛd!"

At that moment the lookout in the bow sang out, "Whitebridge! Whitebridge ahead!"

fəɹ ə lɔŋ mɪnət, ənwɪlɪŋ tə bɪliv ðət mæt kəd seɪ sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðət soʊ kæʒəwəli, ɹænd hɛld ɪz fɹɛnz ɡeɪz əmɪd ðə skɹæmbəl ə seɪlɝz pɹipɛɹɪŋ tə pʊɾ ɪn. mæt ɡlaʊɝɾ əɾ ɪm wɪð ɪz hɛd pʊl daʊn bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. ðəɹ wɑz soʊ mʌtʃ ɹænd wɑntəd tə seɪ, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ɪɾ ɔl ɪndə wɝdz. ðeɪ hæd tə bɪliv ði ʌðɝz wɝ əlaɪv. ðeɪ hæd tə. waɪ? næɡd ə vɔɪs ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz hɛd. soʊ ɪɾəl ɔl tɝn aʊt laɪk wʌn ə tɑmz stɔɹiz? ðə hɪɹoʊz faɪn ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ ən dɪfit ðə vɪlən ən laɪv hæpəli ɛvɝ æftɝ? səm ə hɪz stɔɹiz doʊn ɛn ðət weɪ. səmtaɪmz ivən hɪɹoʊz daɪ. ɑɹ jə ə hɪɹoʊ, ɹænd ælθɹ? ɑɹ jə ə hɪɹoʊ, ʃifɝɾɝ?

For a long minute, unwilling to believe that Mat could say something like that so casually, Rand held his friend's gaze amid the scramble of sailors preparing to put in. Mat glowered at him with his head pulled down between his shoulders. There was so much Rand wanted to say, but he could not manage to get it all into words. They had to believe the others were alive. They had to. Why? nagged a voice in the back of his head. So it will all turn out like one of Thom's stories? The heroes find the treasure and defeat the villain and live happily ever after? Some of his stories don't end that way. Sometimes even heroes die. Are you a hero, Rand al'Thor? Are you a hero, sheepherder?

əbɹʌpli mæt flʌʃt ən pʊld ɪz aɪz əweɪ. fɹid fɹəm ɪz θɔts, ɹænd dʒʌmpt ʌp tə muv θɹu ðə hɝli-bɝli tə ðə ɹeɪl. mæt keɪm æftɝ ɪm sloʊli, nɑɾ ivən meɪkɪŋ ən ɛfɝt tə dɑdʒ ðə seɪlɝz u ɹæn əkɹɔs ɪz pæθ.

Abruptly Mat flushed and pulled his eyes away. Freed from his thoughts, Rand jumped up to move through the hurly-burly to the rail. Mat came after him slowly, not even making an effort to dodge the sailors who ran across his path.

mɛn dæʃt əbaʊt ðə boʊt, bɛɹ fit θʌmpɪŋ ðə dɛk, hɔlɪŋ ɑn ɹoʊps, taɪɪŋ ɔf səm laɪnz ən əntiɪŋ ʌðɝz. səm bɹɔɾ ʌp bɪɡ ɔɪlskɪn bæɡz stʌft ɔlmoʊs tə bɝstɪŋ wɪð wʊl, waɪl ʌðɝz ɹɛɾid keɪbəlz əz θɪk əz ɹændz ɹɪst. dɪspaɪt ðɛɹ heɪst, ðeɪ muvd wɪð ði əʃʊɹəns ə mɛn u hæd dʌn ɪɾ ɔl ə θaʊzən taɪmz bɪfɔɹ, bʌt kæptən doʊmən stʌmpt ʌp ən daʊn ðə dɛk ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz ən kɝsɪŋ ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt muv fæst ɪnʌf tə sut hɪm.

Men dashed about the boat, bare feet thumping the deck, hauling on ropes, tying off some lines and untying others. Some brought up big oilskin bags stuffed almost to bursting with wool, while others readied cables as thick as Rand's wrist. Despite their haste, they moved with the assurance of men who had done it all a thousand times before, but Captain Domon stumped up and down the deck shouting orders and cursing those who did not move fast enough to suit him.

ɹændz ətɛnʃən wɑz ɔl fəɹ wʌt leɪ əhɛd, kʌmɪŋ pleɪnli ɪndə saɪɾ əz ðeɪ ɹaʊndəɾ ə slaɪt bɛn ə ði ɑɹɪnɛl. hi hæd hɝɾ ʌv ɪt, ɪn sɔŋ ən stɔɹi ən pɛdlɝz' teɪlz, bʌt naʊ hi wəɾ æktʃəli  si ðə lɛdʒənd.

Rand's attention was all for what lay ahead, coming plainly into sight as they rounded a slight bend of the Arinelle. He had heard of it, in song and story and peddlers' tales, but now he would actually see the legend.

ðə waɪt bɹɪdʒ ɑɹtʃt haɪ oʊvɝ ðə waɪd wɔɾɝz, twaɪs əz haɪ əz ðə spɹeɪz mæst ən mɔɹ, ən fɹəm ɛn tə ɛn ɪt ɡlimd mɪlki waɪɾ ɪn ðə sʌnlaɪt, ɡæðɝɪŋ ðə laɪɾ əntɪl ɪt sim tə ɡloʊ. spaɪɾɝi pɪɹz ə ðə seɪm stʌf plʌnʒd ɪndə ðə stʃɹɔŋ kɝəns, əpɪɹɪŋ tu fɹeɪl tə səpɔɹt ðə weɪɾ ən wɪdθ ə ðə bɹɪdʒ. ɪt lʊkt ɔl ʌv wʌn pis, əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn kɑɹv fɹəm ə sɪŋɡəl stoʊn əɹ moʊldəd baɪ ə dʒaɪəns hænd, bɹɔɾ ən tɔl, lipɪŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ wɪð ən ɛɹi ɡɹeɪs ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs meɪd ði aɪ fɝɡɛɾ ɪts saɪz. ɔl ɪn ɔl ɪt dwɔɹf ðə taʊn ðət spɹɔld əbaʊɾ ɪts fʊɾ ɑn ði is bæŋk, ðoʊ waɪtbɹɪdʒ wɑz lɑɹdʒɝ baɪ fɑɹ ðən ɛmənz fild, wɪð haʊsəz ə stoʊn ən bɹɪk əz tɔl əz ðoʊz ɪn tɛɹən fɛɹi ən wʊɾən dɑks laɪk θɪn fɪŋɡɝz stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə ɹɪvɝ. smɔl boʊts dɑɾəd ði ɑɹɪnɛl θɪkli, fɪʃɝmɪn hɔlɪŋ ðɛɹ nɛts. ən oʊvɝ ɪɾ ɔl ðə waɪt bɹɪdʒ taʊɝɾ ən ʃoʊn.

The White Bridge arched high over the wide waters, twice as high as the Spray's mast and more, and from end to end it gleamed milky white in the sunlight, gathering the light until it seemed to glow. Spidery piers of the same stuff plunged into the strong currents, appearing too frail to support the weight and width of the bridge. It looked all of one piece, as if it had been carved from a single stone or molded by a giant's hand, broad and tall, leaping the river with an airy grace that almost made the eye forget its size. All in all it dwarfed the town that sprawled about its foot on the east bank, though Whitebridge was larger by far than Emond's Field, with houses of stone and brick as tall as those in Taren Ferry and wooden docks like thin fingers sticking out into the river. Small boats dotted the Arinelle thickly, fishermen hauling their nets. And over it all the White Bridge towered and shone.

"ɪt lʊks laɪk ɡlæs," ɹænd sɛd tə noʊ wʌn ɪn pɝtɪkjəlɝ.

"It looks like glass," Rand said to no one in particular.

kæptən doʊmən pɔz bɪhaɪn ɪm ən tʌkt ɪz θʌmz bɪhaɪn ɪz bɹɔd bɛlt. "neɪ, læd. wʌtɛvɝ ɪt bi, ɪt noʊ bi ɡlæs. nɛvɝ soʊ hɑɹd ðə ɹeɪnz kʌm, ɪt noʊ bi slɪpɝi, ən ðə bɛs tʃɪzəl ən ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəst ɑɹm noʊ meɪk ə mɑɹk ɑn ɪt."

Captain Domon paused behind him and tucked his thumbs behind his broad belt. "Nay, lad. Whatever it be, it no be glass. Never so hard the rains come, it no be slippery, and the best chisel and the strongest arm no make a mark on it."

"ə ɹɛmnən fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz," tɑm sɛd. "aɪ hæv ɔlweɪz θɔɾ ɪt mʌs bi."

"A remnant from the Age of Legends," Thom said. "I have always thought it must be."

ðə kæptən ɡeɪv ə daʊɝ ɡɹʌnt. "meɪæp. bʌt stɪl jusfəl dɪspaɪt. kəd bi sʌmwʌn ɛls bɪlt ɪt. dʌz noʊ hæv tə bi ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝk, fɔɹtʃən pɹɪk mi. ɪt noʊ hæz tə bi soʊ oʊld əz ɔl ðæt. pʊt jəɹ bæk ɪndə ɪt, jə blʌɾi ful!" hi hɝiɾ ɔf daʊn ðə dɛk.

The captain gave a dour grunt. "Mayhap. But still useful despite. Could be someone else built it. Does no have to be Aes Sedai work, Fortune prick me. It no has to be so old as all that. Put your back into it, you bloody fool!" He hurried off down the deck.

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ivən mɔɹ wʌndɝɪŋli. fɹəm ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. meɪd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðɛn. ðət wɑz waɪ kæptən doʊmən fɛl ðə weɪ hi dɪd, fəɹ ɔl ɪz tɔk əbaʊt ðə wʌndɝ ən stʃɹeɪnʒnəs ə ðə wɝld. ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝk. wʌn θɪŋ tə hɪɹ əbaʊɾ ɪt, ənʌðɝ tə si ɪt, ən tʌtʃ ɪt. jə noʊ ðæt, doʊn ju? fəɹ ən ɪnstən ɪt sim tə ɹænd ðəɾ ə ʃædoʊ ɹɪpəl θɹu ðə mɪlk-waɪt stʃɹʌktʃɝ. hi pʊld ɪz aɪz əweɪ, tə ðə dɑks kʌmɪŋ nɪɹɝ, bʌt ðə bɹɪdʒ stɪl lumd ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz vɪʒən.

Rand stared even more wonderingly. From the Age of Legends. Made by Aes Sedai, then. That was why Captain Domon felt the way he did, for all his talk about the wonder and strangeness of the world. Aes Sedai work. One thing to hear about it, another to see it, and touch it. You know that, don't you? For an instant it seemed to Rand that a shadow rippled through the milk-white structure. He pulled his eyes away, to the docks coming nearer, but the bridge still loomed in the corner of his vision.

"wi meɪɾ ɪt, tɑm," hi sɛd, ðən fɔɹst ə læf. "ænd noʊ mjuɾəni."

"We made it, Thom," he said, then forced a laugh. "And no mutiny."

ðə ɡlimən oʊnli hæɹəmft ən blu aʊɾ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz, bʌt tu seɪlɝz ɹɛɾiɪŋ ə keɪbəl nɪɹbaɪ ɡeɪv ɹænd ə ʃɑɹp ɡlæns, ðən bɛn kwɪkli bæk tə ðɛɹ wɝk. hi stɑp læfɪŋ ən tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lʊk ət ðə tu fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ði əpɹoʊtʃ tə waɪtbɹɪdʒ.

The gleeman only harrumphed and blew out his mustaches, but two sailors readying a cable nearby gave Rand a sharp glance, then bent quickly back to their work. He stopped laughing and tried not to look at the two for the rest of the approach to Whitebridge.

ðə spɹeɪ kɝv smuðli ɪn bɪsaɪd ðə fɝs dɑk, θɪk tɪmbɝz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn hɛvi, tɑɹ-koʊɾəd paɪlɪŋz, ən stɑpt wɪð ə bækɪŋ ʌv ɔɹz ðət swɝl ðə wɔɾɝ tə fɹɔθ ɝaʊn ðə bleɪdz. əz ði ɔɹz wɝ dʒɹɔn ɪn, seɪlɝz tɔs keɪbəlz tə mɛn ɑn ðə dɑk, hu fæsən əm ɔf wɪð ə flɝɪʃ, waɪl ʌðɝ kɹumɪn slʌŋ ðə bæɡz ʌv wʊl oʊvɝ ðə saɪd tə pɹətɛk ðə hʌl fɹəm ðə dɑk paɪlɪŋz.

The Spray curved smoothly in beside the first dock, thick timbers sitting on heavy, tar-coated pilings, and stopped with a backing of oars that swirled the water to froth around the blades. As the oars were drawn in, sailors tossed cables to men on the dock, who fastened them off with a flourish, while other crewmen slung the bags of wool over the side to protect the hull from the dock pilings.

bɪfɔɹ ðə boʊt wɑz ivən pʊl snʌɡ əɡɛns ðə dɑk, kæɹɪdʒɪz əpɪɹɾ ət ði ɛn ə ðə dɑk, tɔl ən lækɝd ʃaɪni blæk, itʃ wʌn wɪð ə neɪm peɪntəɾ ɑn ðə dɔɹ ɪn lɑɹdʒ lɛɾɝz, ɡoʊld əɹ skɑɹlət. ðə kæɹɪdʒɪz' pæsənʒɝz hɝiɾ ʌp ðə ɡæŋplæŋk əz sun əz ɪt dʒɹɑpt ɪn pleɪs, smuð-feɪs mɛn ɪn lɔŋ vɛlvət koʊts ən sɪlk-laɪn kloʊks ən klɔθ slɪpɝz, itʃ fɑloʊd baɪ ə pleɪnli dʒɹɛst sɝvən kæɹiɪŋ ɪz aɪɝn-baʊn mʌnibɑks.

Before the boat was even pulled snug against the dock, carriages appeared at the end of the dock, tall and lacquered shiny black, each one with a name painted on the door in large letters, gold or scarlet. The carriages' passengers hurried up the gangplank as soon as it dropped in place, smooth-faced men in long velvet coats and silk-lined cloaks and cloth slippers, each followed by a plainly dressed servant carrying his iron-bound moneybox.

ðeɪ əpɹoʊtʃt kæptən doʊmən wɪð peɪntəd smaɪlz ðət slɪpt wən i əbɹʌpli ɹɔɹɾ ɪn ðɛɹ feɪsəz. "ju!" hi θɹʌst ə θɪk fɪŋɡɝ pæs ðɛm, stɑpɪŋ flɔɹən dʒɛlb ɪn ɪz tʃɹæks ət ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə boʊt. ðə bɹuz ɑn dʒɛlbz fɔɹhɛd fɹəm ɹændz but hæd feɪɾəd əweɪ, bʌɾ i stɪl fɪŋɡɝd ðə spɑt fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm əz ɪf tə ɹimaɪn hɪmsɛlf. "juv slɛpt ɑn wɑtʃ fəɹ ðə læs taɪm ɑn maɪ vɛsəl! əɹ ɑn ɛni vɛsəl, ɪf aɪ hæv maɪ weɪ ʌv ɪt. tʃuz jəɹ oʊn saɪd - ðə dɑk əɹ ðə ɹɪvɝ - bʌɾ ɔf maɪ vɛsəl naʊ!"

They approached Captain Domon with painted smiles that slipped when he abruptly roared in their faces. "You!" He thrust a thick finger past them, stopping Floran Gelb in his tracks at the length of the boat. The bruise on Gelb's forehead from Rand's boot had faded away, but he still fingered the spot from time to time as if to remind himself. "You've slept on watch for the last time on my vessel! Or on any vessel, if I have my way of it. Choose your own side - the dock or the river - but off my vessel now!"

dʒɛlb hʌntʃt ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, ən ɪz aɪz ɡlɪɾɝd heɪɾ ət ɹænd ən ɪz fɹɛnz, ət ɹænd ɪspɛʃli, ə pɔɪzənəs ɡlɛɹ. ðə wɪɹi mæn lʊkt ɝaʊn ðə dɛk fəɹ səpɔɹt, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl hoʊp ɪn ðət lʊk. wʌn baɪ wʌn, ɛvɹi mæn ɪn ðə kɹu stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ ən stɛɹd bæk koʊldli. dʒɛlb wɪltɪd vɪzəbli, bʌt ðən ɪz ɡlɛɹ ɹɪtɝnd, twaɪs əz stʃɹɔŋ əz ɪt hæd bɪn. wɪð ə mʌɾɝd kɝs i dɑɹɾɪd bɪloʊ tə ðə kɹuz kɔɹɾɝz. doʊmən sɛn tu mɛn æftɝ ɪm tə si hi dɪd noʊ mɪstʃəf ən dɪsmɪst ɪm wɪð ə ɡɹʌnt. wən ðə kæptən tɝn bæk tə ðɛm, ðə mɝtʃəns tʊk ʌp ðɛɹ smaɪlz ən baʊz əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɛvɝ bɪn ɪntɝʌptɪd.

Gelb hunched his shoulders, and his eyes glittered hate at Rand and his friends, at Rand especially, a poisonous glare. The wiry man looked around the deck for support, but there was little hope in that look. One by one, every man in the crew straightened from what he was doing and stared back coldly. Gelb wilted visibly, but then his glare returned, twice as strong as it had been. With a muttered curse he darted below to the crew's quarters. Domon sent two men after him to see he did no mischief and dismissed him with a grunt. When the captain turned back to them, the merchants took up their smiles and bows as if they had never been interrupted.

əɾ ə wɝd fɹəm tɑm, mæt ən ɹænd bɪɡæn ɡæðɝɪŋ ðɛɹ θɪŋz təɡɛðɝ. ðəɹ wɑz nɑt mʌtʃ əsaɪd fɹəm ðə kloʊðz ɑn ðɛɹ bæks, nɑt fəɹ ɛni ʌv ðɛm. ɹænd hæɾ ɪz blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl ən sæɾəlbæɡz, ən ɪz fɑðɝz sɔɹd. hi hɛl ðə sɔɹd fəɹ ə mɪnət, ən hoʊmsɪknəs ɹoʊld oʊvɝ ɪm soʊ stʃɹɔŋli ðəɾ ɪz aɪz stʌŋ. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf i wəɾ ɛvɝ si tæm əɡɛn. əɹ hoʊm? hoʊm. gɑnə spɛn ðə ɹɛst ə jəɹ laɪf ɹʌnɪŋ, ɹʌnɪŋ ən əfɹeɪɾ ə jəɹ oʊn dʒɹimz. wɪð ə ʃʌɾɝɪŋ saɪ hi slɪp ðə bɛlt ɝaʊn ɪz weɪst oʊvɝ ɪz koʊt.

At a word from Thom, Mat and Rand began gathering their things together. There was not much aside from the clothes on their backs, not for any of them. Rand had his blanketroll and saddlebags, and his father's sword. He held the sword for a minute, and homesickness rolled over him so strongly that his eyes stung. He wondered if he would ever see Tam again. Or home? Home. Going to spend the rest of your life running, running and afraid of your own dreams. With a shuddering sigh he slipped the belt around his waist over his coat.

dʒɛlb keɪm bæk ɑn dɛk, fɑloʊd baɪ hɪz twɪn ʃædoʊz. hi lʊk stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛd, bʌt ɹænd kəd stɪl fil heɪtʃɹəd kʌmɪŋ ɔf ɪm ɪn weɪvz. bæk ɹɪdʒəɾ ən feɪs dɑɹk, dʒɛlb wɔk stɪf-lɛɡəd daʊn ðə ɡæŋplæŋk ən pʊʃt ɹʌfli ɪndə ðə θɪn kɹaʊɾ ɑn ðə dɑk. ɪn ə mɪnəɾ i wɑz ɡɔn fɹəm saɪt, vænɪʃt bɪɑn ðə mɝtʃəns' kæɹɪdʒɪz.

Gelb came back on deck, followed by his twin shadows. He looked straight ahead, but Rand could still feel hatred coming off him in waves. Back rigid and face dark, Gelb walked stiff-legged down the gangplank and pushed roughly into the thin crowd on the dock. In a minute he was gone from sight, vanished beyond the merchants' carriages.

ðəɹ wɝ nɑɾ ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni pipəl ɑn ðə dɑk, ən ðoʊz wɝ ə pleɪnli dʒɹɛs mɪks ʌv wɝkmɪn, fɪʃɝmɪn mɛndɪŋ nɛts, ən ə fju taʊnzpipəl u hæd kʌm aʊt tə si ðə fɝs boʊɾ ə ðə jɪɹ tə kʌm daʊnɹɪvɝ fɹəm sɑldɑiə. nʌn ə ðə ɡɝlz wɑz ɛɡwin ən noʊ wʌn lʊk ðə lis bɪt laɪk mɔɪɹeɪn, əɹ læn, əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls ɹænd wɑz hoʊpɪŋ tə si.

There were not a great many people on the dock, and those were a plainly dressed mix of workmen, fishermen mending nets, and a few townspeople who had come out to see the first boat of the year to come downriver from Saldaea. None of the girls was Egwene and no one looked the least bit like Moiraine, or Lan, or anyone else Rand was hoping to see.

"meɪbi ðeɪ dɪdn kʌm daʊn tə ðə dɑk," hi sɛd.

"Maybe they didn't come down to the dock," he said.

"meɪbi," tɑm ɹɪplaɪd kɝtli. hi sɛɾəld ɪz ɪnstʃɹəmən keɪsəz ɑn ɪz bæk wɪð kɛɹ. "ju tu kip ən aɪ aʊt fəɹ dʒɛlb. hɪl meɪk tʃɹʌbəl ɪf i kæn. wi wɑnə pæs θɹu waɪtbɹɪdʒ soʊ sɔfli ðət noʊbɑdi ɹɪmɛmbɝz wi wɝ hɪɹ faɪv mɪnəts æftɝ wɝ ɡɔn."

"Maybe," Thom replied curtly. He settled his instrument cases on his back with care. "You two keep an eye out for Gelb. He will make trouble if he can. We want to pass through Whitebridge so softly that nobody remembers we were here five minutes after we're gone."

ðɛɹ kloʊks flæpt ɪn ðə wɪn əz ðeɪ wɔk tə ðə ɡæŋplæŋk. mæt kæɹiɾ ɪz baʊ kɹɔst ɪn fɹʌn ɑn ɪz tʃɛst. ivən æftɝ ɔl ðɛɹ deɪz ɑn ðə boʊt, ɪt stɪl ɡɑɾ ə fju lʊks fɹəm ðə kɹumɪn; ðɛɹ baʊz wɝ ʃɔɹɾ əfɛɹz.

Their cloaks flapped in the wind as they walked to the gangplank. Mat carried his bow crossed in front on his chest. Even after all their days on the boat, it still got a few looks from the crewmen; their bows were short affairs.

kæptən doʊmən lɛf ðə mɝtʃəns tə ɪntɝsɛp tɑm ət ðə ɡæŋplæŋk.

Captain Domon left the merchants to intercept Thom at the gangplank.

"ju bi livɪŋ mi naʊ, ɡlimən? kən aɪ noʊ tɔk jə ɪndə kəntɪnjuɪŋ ɑn? aɪ bi ɡoʊɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ daʊn tə ɪljən, wɛɹ foʊk əv ə pɹɑpɝ ɹəɡɑɹd fəɹ ɡlimən. ðəɹ bi noʊ faɪnɝ pleɪs ɪn ðə wɝl fəɹ jəɹ ɑɹt. aɪd ɡɛt jə ðəɹ ɪn ɡʊd taɪm fəɹ ðə fist ə sɪfæn. ðə kɑmpətɪʃənz, jə noʊ. ə hʌnʒɹəd ɡoʊl mɑɹks fəɹ ðə bɛs tɛlɪŋ ə ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn."

"You be leaving me now, gleeman? Can I no talk you into continuing on? I be going all the way down to Illian, where folk have a proper regard for gleemen. There be no finer place in the world for your art. I'd get you there in good time for the Feast of Sefan. The competitions, you know. A hundred gold marks for the best telling of The Great Hunt of the Horn."

"ə ɡɹeɪt pɹaɪz, kæptən," tɑm ɹɪplaɪd wɪð ən ɪlæbɹət baʊ ən ə flɝɪʃ ə hɪz kloʊk ðət sɛt ðə pætʃəz tə flʌɾɝɪŋ, "ænd ɡɹeɪt kɑmpətɪʃənz, wɪtʃ ɹaɪtli dʒɹɔ ɡlimən fɹəm ðə hoʊl wɝld oʊvɝ. bʌt," hi æɾəd dʒɹaɪli, "aɪ fɪɹ wi kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹd ðə fɛɹ ət ðə ɹeɪts jə tʃɑɹdʒ."

"A great prize, Captain," Thom replied with an elaborate bow and a flourish of his cloak that set the patches to fluttering, "and great competitions, which rightly draw gleemen from the whole world over. But," he added dryly, "I fear we could not afford the fare at the rates you charge."

"aɪ, wɛl, əz tə ðæt. . . ." ðə kæptən pɹədust ə lɛðɝ pɝs fɹəm ɪz koʊt pɑkəɾ ən tɔst ɪt tə tɑm. ɪt klɪŋkt wən tɑm kɑɾ ɪt. "jɔɹ fɛɹz bæk, ən ə bɪt mɔɹ bɪsaɪdz. ðə dæmədʒ wɑz noʊ soʊ bæɾ əz aɪ θɔt, ən juv wɝk jəɹ weɪ ən mɔɹ wɪð jəɹ teɪlz ən jəɹ hɑɹp. aɪ kəd meɪbi mænədʒ əz mʌtʃ əɡɛn ɪf jə steɪ əbɔɹd tə ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz. ən aɪ wəd sɛt jə əʃɔɹ ɪn ɪljən. ə ɡʊd ɡlimən kən meɪk ɪz fɔɹtʃən ðɛɹ, ivən əsaɪd fɹəm ðə kɑmpətɪʃənz."

"Aye, well, as to that. . . ." The captain produced a leather purse from his coat pocket and tossed it to Thom. It clinked when Thom caught it. "Your fares back, and a bit more besides. The damage was no so bad as I thought, and you've worked your way and more with your tales and your harp. I could maybe manage as much again if you stay aboard to the Sea of Storms. And I would set you ashore in Illian. A good gleeman can make his fortune there, even aside from the competitions."

tɑm hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, weɪɪŋ ðə pɝs ɑn ɪz pɑm, bʌt ɹænd spoʊk ʌp. "wɝ miɾɪŋ fɹɛnz hɪɹ, kæptən, ən ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn tə keɪɛmlɪn təɡɛðɝ. wɪl əv tə si ɪljən ənʌðɝ taɪm."

Thom hesitated, weighing the purse on his palm, but Rand spoke up. "We're meeting friends here, Captain, and going on to Caemlyn together. We'll have to see Illian another time."

tɑmz maʊθ twɪstəd ɹaɪli, ðən i blu aʊɾ ɪz lɔŋ mʌstæʃɪz ən tʌk ðə pɝs ɪndə hɪz pɑkət. "pɝhæps ɪf ðə pipəl wəɹ tə miɾ ɑɹ nɑt hɪɹ, kæptən."

Thom's mouth twisted wryly, then he blew out his long mustaches and tucked the purse into his pocket. "Perhaps if the people we are to meet are not here, Captain."

"aɪ," doʊmən sɛd saʊɝli. "ju θɪŋk ɑn ɪt. tu bæɾ aɪ kən noʊ kip dʒɛlb əbɔɹd tə teɪk ði ʌðɝz' æŋɡɝ, bʌɾ aɪ də wʌɾ aɪ seɪ əl du. aɪ səpoʊz aɪ mʌst iz ʌp naʊ, ivən ɪf ɪt minz teɪkɪŋ θɹi taɪmz əz lɔŋ tə ɹitʃ ɪljən əz aɪ ʃʊd. wɛl, meɪæp ðoʊz tʃɹɑləks wɝ æftɝ jə θɹi."

"Aye," Domon said sourly. "You think on it. Too bad I can no keep Gelb aboard to take the others' anger, but I do what I say I will do. I suppose I must ease up now, even if it means taking three times as long to reach Illian as I should. Well, mayhap those Trollocs were after you three."

ɹænd blɪŋk bʌt kɛp saɪlənt, bʌt mæt wɑz nɑt soʊ kɔʃəs. "waɪ dʒju θɪŋk ðeɪ wɝnt?" hi dɪmændəd. "ðeɪ wɝ æftɝ ðə seɪm tʃɹɛʒɝ wi wɝ hʌntɪŋ."

Rand blinked but kept silent, but Mat was not so cautious. "Why do you think they weren't?" he demanded. "They were after the same treasure we were hunting."

"meɪæp," ðə kæptən ɡɹʌntɪd, saʊndɪŋ ʌnkənvɪnst. hi koʊm θɪk fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɪz bɪɹd, ðən pɔɪntəɾ ət ðə pɑkət wɛɹ tɑm hæd pʊt ðə pɝs. "twaɪs ðəɾ ɪf jə kʌm bæk tə kip ðə mɛnz maɪnz ɔf haʊ hɑɹɾ aɪ wɝk ðɛm. θɪŋk ɑn ɪt. aɪ seɪl wɪð ðə fɝs laɪɾ ɑn ðə mɑɹoʊ." hi tɝn ɑn ɪz hil ən stʃɹoʊd bæk tə ðə mɝtʃəns, ɑɹmz spɹɛɾɪŋ waɪɾ əz i bɪɡæn ən əpɑlədʒi fəɹ kipɪŋ əm weɪɾɪŋ.

"Mayhap," the captain grunted, sounding unconvinced. He combed thick fingers through his beard, then pointed at the pocket where Thom had put the purse. "Twice that if you come back to keep the men's minds off how hard I work them. Think on it. I sail with the first light on the morrow." He turned on his heel and strode back to the merchants, arms spreading wide as he began an apology for keeping them waiting.

tɑm stɪl hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, bʌt ɹænd hʌsəld ɪm daʊn ðə ɡæŋplæŋk wɪθaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ ɪm ə tʃæns tə ɑɹɡju, ən ðə ɡlimən lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi hɝɾɪd. ə mɝmɝ pæs θɹu ðə pipəl ɑn ðə dɑk əz ðeɪ sɔ tɑmz pætʃ-kʌvɝd kloʊk, ən səm kɔld aʊt tə dɪskʌvɝ wɛɹ i wəd bi pɝfɔɹmɪŋ. soʊ mʌtʃ fəɹ nɑt biɪŋ noʊɾəst, ɹænd θɔt, dɪsmeɪd. baɪ sʌndaʊn ɪt wəd bi ɔl oʊvɝ waɪtbɹɪdʒ ðət ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡlimən ɪn taʊn. hi hɝid tɑm əlɔŋ, ðoʊ, ən tɑm, ɹæpt ɪn sʌlki saɪləns, dɪd nɑɾ ivən tʃɹaɪ tə sloʊ daʊn ɪnʌf tə pɹin ʌndɝ ði ətɛnʃən.

Thom still hesitated, but Rand hustled him down the gangplank without giving him a chance to argue, and the gleeman let himself be herded. A murmur passed through the people on the dock as they saw Thom's patch-covered cloak, and some called out to discover where he would be performing. So much for not being noticed, Rand thought, dismayed. By sundown it would be all over Whitebridge that there was a gleeman in town. He hurried Thom along, though, and Thom, wrapped in sulky silence, did not even try to slow down enough to preen under the attention.

ðə kæɹɪdʒ dʒɹaɪvɝz lʊk daʊn ət tɑm wɪð ɪntʃɹəs fɹəm ðɛɹ haɪ pɝtʃɪz, bʌɾ əpɛɹənli ðə dɪɡnəɾi ʌv ðɛɹ pəzɪʃənz fɝbeɪd ʃaʊɾɪŋ. wɪð noʊ aɪdiə ʌv wɛɹ tə ɡoʊ ɪɡzækli, ɹænd tɝn ʌp ðə stʃɹit ðət ɹæn əlɔŋ ðə ɹɪvɝ ən ʌndɝ ðə bɹɪdʒ.

The carriage drivers looked down at Thom with interest from their high perches, but apparently the dignity of their positions forbade shouting. With no idea of where to go exactly, Rand turned up the street that ran along the river and under the bridge.

"wi nid tə faɪn mɔɪɹeɪn ən ði ʌðɝz," hi sɛd. "æn fæst. wi ʃʊɾə θɔɾ ə tʃeɪnʒɪŋ tɑmz kloʊk."

"We need to find Moiraine and the others," he said. "And fast. We should have thought of changing Thom's cloak."

tɑm sʌɾənli ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf ən stɑp dɛd. "æn ɪnkipɝ wɪl bi eɪbəl tə tɛl əs ɪf ðəɹ hɪɹ, əɹ ɪf ðeɪv pæs θɹu. ðə ɹaɪɾ ɪnkipɝ. ɪnkipɝz əv ɔl ðə nuz ən ɡɑsəp. ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹən hɪɹ. . . ."hi lʊk bæk ən fɔɹθ fɹəm ɹænd tə mæt.
