"wi hæv tə tɔk, wi θɹi." kloʊk swɝlɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪz æŋkəlz, hi sɛɾ ɔf ɪndə ðə taʊn, əweɪ fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ. ɹænd ən mæt hæd tə stɛp kwɪkli tə kip ʌp.

Thom suddenly shook himself and stopped dead. "An innkeeper will be able to tell us if they're here, or if they've passed through. The right innkeeper. Innkeepers have all the news and gossip. If they aren't here. . . ."He looked back and forth from Rand to Mat. "We have to talk, we three." Cloak swirling around his ankles, he set off into the town, away from the river. Rand and Mat had to step quickly to keep up.

ðə bɹɔd, mɪlk-waɪɾ ɑɹtʃ ðət ɡeɪv ðə taʊn ɪts neɪm dɑməneɪɾəd waɪtbɹɪdʒ əz mʌtʃ kloʊs ʌp əz ɪt dɪd fɹəm əfɑɹ, bʌt wʌns ɹænd wɑz ɪn ðə stʃɹits i ɹilaɪz ðət ðə taʊn wɑz ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz bɪɡ əz bɛɹlən, ðoʊ nɑt soʊ kɹaʊɾəd wɪð pipəl. ə fju kɑɹts muvd ɪn ðə stʃɹits, pʊl baɪ hɔɹs əɹ ɑks əɹ dɑŋki əɹ mæn, bʌt noʊ kæɹɪdʒɪz. ðoʊz moʊs laɪkli ɔl bɪlɔŋ tə ðə mɝtʃəns ən wɝ klʌstɝd daʊn ət ðə dɑk.

The broad, milk-white arch that gave the town its name dominated Whitebridge as much close up as it did from afar, but once Rand was in the streets he realized that the town was every bit as big as Baerlon, though not so crowded with people. A few carts moved in the streets, pulled by horse or ox or donkey or man, but no carriages. Those most likely all belonged to the merchants and were clustered down at the dock.

ʃɑps ʌv ɛvɹi dɪskɹɪpʃən laɪn ðə stʃɹits, ən mɛni ʌv ðə tʃɹeɪdzmən wɝkt ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛɹ ɛstæblɪʃməns, ʌndɝ ðə saɪnz swɪŋɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd. ðeɪ pæst ə mæn mɛndɪŋ pɑts, ən ə teɪlɝ hoʊldɪŋ foʊlz ə klɔθ ʌp tə ðə laɪt fəɹ ə kʌstəmɝ. ə ʃumeɪkɝ, sɪɾɪŋ ɪn ɪz dɔɹweɪ, tæpt ɪz hæmɝ ɑn ðə hil ʌv ə but. hɔkɝz kɹaɪd ðɛɹ sɝvəsəz ət ʃɑɹpənɪŋ naɪvz ən sɪzɝz, əɹ tʃɹaɪd tə ɪntʃɹəs ðə pæsɝzbi ɪn ðɛɹ skɪmpi tʃɹeɪz ə fɹuɾ əɹ vɛdʒtəbəlz, bʌt nʌn wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ mʌtʃ ɪntʃɹəst. ʃɑps sɛlɪŋ fud hæd ðə seɪm pɪɾəfəl dɪspleɪz ə pɹədus ɹænd ɹɪmɛmbɝd fɹəm bɛɹlən. ivən ðə fɪʃmɑŋɡɝz dɪspleɪɾ oʊnli smɔl paɪlz ə smɔl fɪʃ, fəɹ ɔl ðə boʊts ɑn ðə ɹɪvɝ. taɪmz wɝ nɑt ɹɪli hɑɹd jɛt, bʌɾ ɛvɹiwʌn kəd si wʌt wɑz kʌmɪŋ ɪf ðə wɛðɝ dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ sun, ən ðoʊz feɪsəz ðət wɝ nɑt fɪkst ɪndə wɝid fɹaʊnz sim tə stɛɹ ət sʌmθɪŋ ənsin, sʌmθɪŋ ənplɛzənt.

Shops of every description lined the streets, and many of the tradesmen worked in front of their establishments, under the signs swinging in the wind. They passed a man mending pots, and a tailor holding folds of cloth up to the light for a customer. A shoemaker, sitting in his doorway, tapped his hammer on the heel of a boot. Hawkers cried their services at sharpening knives and scissors, or tried to interest the passersby in their skimpy trays of fruit or vegetables, but none was getting much interest. Shops selling food had the same pitiful displays of produce Rand remembered from Baerlon. Even the fishmongers displayed only small piles of small fish, for all the boats on the river. Times were not really hard yet, but everyone could see what was coming if the weather did not change soon, and those faces that were not fixed into worried frowns seemed to stare at something unseen, something unpleasant.

wɛɹ ðə waɪt bɹɪdʒ keɪm daʊn ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə taʊn wɑz ə bɪɡ skwɛɹ, peɪvd wɪð stoʊnz wɔɹn baɪ dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz ə fiɾ ən wæɡən wilz. ɪnz sɝaʊndəd ðə skwɛɹ, ən ʃɑps, ən tɔl, ɹɛd bɹɪk haʊsəz wɪð saɪnz aʊt fɹʌn bɛɹɪŋ ðə seɪm neɪmz ɹænd hæd sin ɑn ðə kæɹɪdʒɪz ət ðə dɑk. ɪt wɑz ɪndə wʌn ə ðoʊz ɪnz, simɪŋli tʃoʊzən ət ɹændəm, ðət tɑm dʌkt. ðə saɪn oʊvɝ ðə dɔɹ, swɪŋɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd, hæɾ ə stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ mæn wɪð ə bʌndəl ɑn ɪz bæk ɑn wʌn saɪɾ ən ðə seɪm mæn wɪð ɪz hɛɾ ɑn ə pɪloʊ ɑn ði ʌðɝ, ən pɹoʊkleɪm ðə weɪfɛɹɝz' ɹɛst.

Where the White Bridge came down in the center of the town was a big square, paved with stones worn by generations of feet and wagon wheels. Inns surrounded the square, and shops, and tall, red brick houses with signs out front bearing the same names Rand had seen on the carriages at the dock. It was into one of those inns, seemingly chosen at random, that Thom ducked. The sign over the door, swinging in the wind, had a striding man with a bundle on his back on one side and the same man with his head on a pillow on the other, and proclaimed The Wayfarers' Rest.

ðə kɑmən ɹum stʊɾ ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə fæɾ ɪnkipɝ dʒɹɔɪŋ eɪl fɹəm ə bæɹəl ən tu mɛn ɪn ɹʌf wɝkmənz kloʊðz stɛɹɪŋ ɡlʌmli ɪndə ðɛɹ mʌɡz əɾ ə teɪbəl ɪn ðə bæk. oʊnli ði ɪnkipɝ lʊkt ʌp wən ðeɪ keɪm ɪn. ə ʃoʊldɝ-haɪ wɔl splɪt ðə ɹum ɪn tu fɹəm fɹʌn tə bæk, wɪð teɪbəlz ən ə bleɪzɪŋ faɪɝpleɪs ɑn itʃ saɪd. ɹænd wʌndɝɾ aɪdli ɪf ɔl ɪnkipɝz wɝ fæɾ ən luzɪŋ ðɛɹ hɛɹ.

The common room stood empty except for the fat innkeeper drawing ale from a barrel and two men in rough workman's clothes staring glumly into their mugs at a table in the back. Only the innkeeper looked up when they came in. A shoulder-high wall split the room in two from front to back, with tables and a blazing fireplace on each side. Rand wondered idly if all innkeepers were fat and losing their hair.

ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ bɹɪskli, tɑm kɑmɛntəd tə ði ɪnkipɝ ɑn ðə leɪt koʊld ən ɔɹɾɝd hɑt spaɪst waɪn, ðən æɾəd kwaɪətli, "ɪz ðəɹ sʌmwɛɹ maɪ fɹɛnz ən aɪ kəd tɔk wɪθaʊt biɪŋ dɪstɝbd?"

Rubbing his hands together briskly, Thom commented to the innkeeper on the late cold and ordered hot spiced wine, then added quietly, "Is there somewhere my friends and I could talk without being disturbed?"

ði ɪnkipɝ nɑɾəd tə ðə loʊ wɔl. "ði ʌðɝ saɪd ðæts əz bɛst aɪv ɡɑɾ ənlɛs jə wɑnə teɪk ə ɹum. fəɹ wən seɪlɝz kʌm ʌp fɹəm ðə ɹɪvɝ. simz laɪk hæf ðə kɹuz ɡɑt ɡɹʌdʒɪz əɡɛns ði ʌðɝ hæf. aɪ woʊn əv maɪ pleɪs bɹoʊk ʌp baɪ faɪts, soʊ aɪ kip əm əpɑɹt." hi hæd bɪn aɪɪŋ tɑmz kloʊk ðə hoʊl waɪl, ən naʊ hi kɑkt ɪz hɛd tə wʌn saɪd, ə slaɪ lʊk ɪn ɪz aɪz. "ju steɪɪŋ? hævən hæɾ ə ɡlimən hɪɹ ɪn səm taɪm. foʊks wəd peɪ ɹil ɡʊd fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ əz wəd teɪk ðɛɹ maɪnz ɔf θɪŋz. aɪɾ ivən teɪk səm ɔf ɑn jəɹ ɹum ən milz."

The innkeeper nodded to the low wall. "The other side that's as best I've got unless you want to take a room. For when sailors come up from the river. Seems like half the crews got grudges against the other half. I won't have my place broke up by fights, so I keep them apart." He had been eyeing Thom's cloak the whole while, and now he cocked his head to one side, a sly look in his eyes. "You staying? Haven't had a gleeman here in some time. Folks would pay real good for something as would take their minds off things. I'd even take some off on your room and meals."

ənnoʊɾɪst, ɹænd θɔt ɡlʌmli.

Unnoticed, Rand thought glumly.

"ju ɑɹ tu dʒɛnɝəs," tɑm sɛd wɪð ə smuð baʊ. "pɝhæps əl teɪk ʌp jəɹ ɔfɝ. bʌt fəɹ naʊ, ə lɪɾəl pɹaɪvəsi."

"You are too generous," Thom said with a smooth bow. "Perhaps I will take up your offer. But for now, a little privacy."

"aɪl bɹɪŋ jəɹ waɪn. ɡʊd mʌni hɪɹ fəɹ ə ɡlimən."

"I'll bring your wine. Good money here for a gleeman."

ðə teɪbəlz ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə wɔl wɝ ɔl ɛmpti, bʌt tɑm tʃoʊz wʌn ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə speɪs. "soʊ noʊ wʌn kən lɪsən wɪθaʊɾ əs noʊɪŋ," hi ɪkspleɪnd. "dɪd jə hɪɹ ðət fɛloʊ? hɪl teɪk səm ɔf. waɪ, aɪd dʌbəl ɪz kʌstəm dʒʌs baɪ sɪɾɪŋ hɪɹ. ɛni ɑnəst ɪnkipɝ ɡɪvz ə ɡlimən ɹum ən bɔɹɾ ən ə ɡʊd bɪt bɪsaɪdz."

The tables on the far side of the wall were all empty, but Thom chose one right in the middle of the space. "So no one can listen without us knowing," he explained. "Did you hear that fellow? He'll take some off. Why, I'd double his custom just by sitting here. Any honest innkeeper gives a gleeman room and board and a good bit besides."

ðə bɛɹ teɪbəl wɑz nʌn tu klin, ən ðə flɔɹ hæd nɑt bɪn swɛpt ɪn deɪz ɪf nɑt wiks. ɹænd lʊkt ɝaʊn ən ɡɹɪməst. mæstɝ ælvɪɹ wəd nɑɾ əv lɛɾ ɪz ɪn ɡɛt ðət dɝɾi ɪf i hæd hæd tə klaɪm aʊɾ ʌv ə sɪkb tə si tə ɪt. "wɝ oʊnli æftɝ ɪnfɝmeɪʃən. ɹɪmɛmbɝ?"

The bare table was none too clean, and the floor had not been swept in days if not weeks. Rand looked around and grimaced. Master al'Vere would not have let his inn get that dirty if he had had to climb out of a sickbed to see to it. "We're only after information. Remember?"

"waɪ hɪɹ?" mæt dɪmændəd. "wi pæst ʌðɝ ɪnz ðət lʊkt klinɝ."

"Why here?" Mat demanded. "We passed other inns that looked cleaner."

"stʃɹeɪɾ ɑn fɹəm ðə bɹɪdʒ," tɑm sɛd, "ɪz ðə ɹoʊd tə keɪɛmlɪn. ɛniwʌn pæsɪŋ θɹu waɪtbɹɪdʒ kʌmz θɹu ðɪs skwɛɹ, ənlɛs ðəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ baɪ ɹɪvɝ, ən wi noʊ jəɹ fɹɛnz ɑɹən duɪŋ ðæt. ɪf ðəɹ ɪz noʊ wɝɾ ə ðɛm hɪɹ, ɪt dʌzn ɪɡzɪst. lemi də ðə tɔkɪŋ. ðɪs əz tə bi dʌn kɛɹfəli."

"Straight on from the bridge," Thom said, "is the road to Caemlyn. Anyone passing through Whitebridge comes through this square, unless they're going by river, and we know your friends aren't doing that. If there is no word of them here, it doesn't exist. Let me do the talking. This has to be done carefully."

dʒʌs ðən ði ɪnkipɝ əpɪɹd, θɹi bæɾɝd pjuɾɝ mʌɡz ɡɹɪpt ɪn wʌn fɪs baɪ ðə hændəlz. ðə fæt mæn flɪkt ət ðə teɪbəl wɪð ə taʊəl, sɛt ðə mʌɡz daʊn, ən tʊk tɑmz mʌni. "ɪf jə steɪ, jə woʊn əv tə peɪ fəɹ jəɹ dʒɹɪŋks. ɡʊd waɪn, hɪɹ."

Just then the innkeeper appeared, three battered pewter mugs gripped in one fist by the handles. The fat man flicked at the table with a towel, set the mugs down, and took Thom's money. "If you stay, you won't have to pay for your drinks. Good wine, here."

tɑmz smaɪl tʌtʃt oʊnli hɪz maʊθ. "aɪ wɪl θɪŋk ɑn ɪt, ɪnkipɝ. wʌt nuz ɪz ðɛɹ? wɪv bɪn əweɪ fɹəm hɪɹɪŋ θɪŋz."

Thom's smile touched only his mouth. "I will think on it, innkeeper. What news is there? We have been away from hearing things."

"bɪɡ nuz, ðæts wʌt. bɪɡ nuz."

"Big news, that's what. Big news."

ði ɪnkipɝ dʒɹeɪp ðə taʊəl oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ən pʊld ʌp ə tʃɛɹ. hi kɹɔst ɪz ɑɹmz ɑn ðə teɪbəl, tʊk ɹut wɪð ə lɔŋ saɪ, seɪɪŋ wʌɾ ə kʌmfɝɾ ɪt wɑz tə ɡɛɾ ɔf ɪz fit. hɪz neɪm wɑz bɑɹɾɪm, ən i wɛn ɑn əbaʊɾ ɪz fiɾ ɪn dɪteɪl, əbaʊt kɔɹnz ən bunjənz ən haʊ mʌtʃ taɪm i spɛn stændɪŋ ən wʌɾ i soʊkt əm ɪn, əntɪl tɑm mɛnʃən ðə nuz, əɡɛn, ən ðən i ʃɪftəɾ oʊvɝ wɪð hɑɹdli ə pɔz.

The innkeeper draped the towel over his shoulder and pulled up a chair. He crossed his arms on the table, took root with a long sigh, saying what a comfort it was to get off his feet. His name was Bartim, and he went on about his feet in detail, about corns and bunions and how much time he spent standing and what he soaked them in, until Thom mentioned the news, again, and then he shifted over with hardly a pause.

ðə nuz wɑz dʒʌst əz bɪɡ əz i sɛɾ ɪt wɑz. lɑɡən, ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən, hæd bɪn kæptʃɝɾ æftɝ ə bɪɡ bæɾəl nɪɹ luɡɹd waɪl i wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə muv ɪz ɑɹmi fɹəm ɡildən tə tɛɹ. ðə pɹɑfəsiz, ðeɪ ʌndɝstʊd? tɑm nɑɾəd, ən bɑɹɾɪm wɛn ɑn. ðə ɹoʊdz ɪn ðə saʊθ wɝ pækt wɪð pipəl, ðə lʌki wʌnz wɪð wʌt ðeɪ kəd kæɹi ɑn ðɛɹ bæks. θaʊzənz fliɪŋ ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz.

The news was just as big as he said it was. Logain, the false Dragon, had been captured after a big battle near Lugard while he was trying to move his army from Ghealdan to Tear. The Prophecies, they understood? Thom nodded, and Bartim went on. The roads in the south were packed with people, the lucky ones with what they could carry on their backs. Thousands fleeing in all directions.

"nʌn" - bɑɹɾɪm tʃʌkəld ɹaɪli - "səpɔɹɾəd lɑɡən, ʌv kɔɹs. oʊ, noʊ, jə woʊn faɪn mɛni tə ədmɪt tə ðæt, nɑt naʊ. dʒʌst ɹɛfjudʒiz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ə seɪf pleɪs dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹʌbəlz."

"None" - Bartim chuckled wryly - "supported Logain, of course. Oh, no, you won't find many to admit to that, not now. Just refugees trying to find a safe place during the troubles."

ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd bɪn ɪnvɑlvd ɪn teɪkɪŋ lɑɡən, ʌv kɔɹs. bɑɹɾɪm spæɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ wən i sɛd ðæt, ən əɡɛn wən i sɛd ðeɪ wɝ teɪkɪŋ ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən nɔɹθ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. bɑɹɾɪm wɑz ə disən mæn, hi sɛd, ə ɹɪspɛktəbəl mæn, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ kəɾ ɔl ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə blaɪt wɛɹ ðeɪ keɪm fɹəm ən teɪk tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪð ðɛm, əz fɑɹ əz i wɑz kənsɝnd. hi wəd ɡɛt noʊ kloʊsɝ tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ðən ə θaʊzən maɪlz, ɪf i hæɾ ɪz weɪ. ʌv kɔɹs, ðeɪ wɝ stɑpɪŋ əɾ ɛvɹi vɪlədʒ ən taʊn ɑn ðə weɪ nɔɹθ tə dɪspleɪ lɑɡən, soʊ hi hæd hɝd. tə ʃoʊ pipəl ðət ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən hæd bɪn teɪkən ən ðə wɝld wɑz seɪf əɡɛn. hi wʊɾə laɪk tə si ðæt, ivən ɪf ɪt dɪd min ɡɛɾɪŋ kloʊs tə ɛɛs sədaɪ. hi wɑz hæfweɪ tɛmptəd tə ɡoʊ tə keɪɛmlɪn.

Aes Sedai had been involved in taking Logain, of course. Bartim spat on the floor when he said that, and again when he said they were taking the false Dragon north to Tar Valon. Bartim was a decent man, he said, a respectable man, and Aes Sedai could all go back to the Blight where they came from and take Tar Valon with them, as far as he was concerned. He would get no closer to an Aes Sedai than a thousand miles, if he had his way. Of course, they were stopping at every village and town on the way north to display Logain, so he had heard. To show people that the false Dragon had been taken and the world was safe again. He would have liked to see that, even if it did mean getting close to Aes Sedai. He was halfway tempted to go to Caemlyn.

"ðeɪl bi teɪkɪŋ ɪm ðəɹ tə ʃoʊ tə kwin mɔɹɡeɪs." ði ɪnkipɝ tʌtʃt ɪz fɔɹhɛd ɹɪspɛkfəli. "aɪv nɛvɝ sin ðə kwin. mæn ɔt tə si hɪz oʊn kwin, doʊn jə θɪŋk?"

"They'll be taking him there to show to Queen Morgase." The innkeeper touched his forehead respectfully. "I've never seen the Queen. Man ought to see his own Queen, don't you think?"

lɑɡən kəd də "θɪŋz," ən ðə weɪ bɑɹɾɪmz aɪz ʃɪftəɾ ən ɪz tʌŋ dɑɹɾɪd əkɹɔs ɪz lɪps meɪɾ ɪt klɪɹ wʌɾ i mɛnt. hi hæd sin ðə læs fɔls dʒɹæɡən, tu jɪɹz əɡoʊ, wən i wɑz pɝeɪɾɪd θɹu ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd, bʌt ðət wɑz dʒʌst səm fɛloʊ hu θɔɾ i kəd meɪk hɪmsɛlf ə kɪŋ. ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ nid fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðət taɪm. soʊlʒɝz hæd hæɾ ɪm tʃeɪn ʌp ɑn ə wæɡən. ə sʌlən-lʊkɪŋ fɛloʊ hu moʊn ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə wæɡoʊnbd, kʌvɝɪŋ ɪz hɛd wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz wɛnɛvɝ pipəl θɹu stoʊnz əɹ poʊkt ɪm wɪð stɪks. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə lɑɾ ə ðæt, ən ðə soʊlʒɝz hæd dʌn nʌθɪŋ tə stɑp ɪt, əz lɔŋ əz ðeɪ dɪd nɑt kɪl ðə fɛloʊ. bɛs tə lɛt ðə pipəl si hi wɑz nʌθɪŋ spɛʃəl æftɝ ɔl. hi kəd nɑt də "θɪŋz." ðɪs lɑɡən wəd bi sʌmθɪŋ tə si, ðoʊ. sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ bɑɹɾɪm tə tɛl ɪz ɡɹæntʃɪlʒɹən əbaʊt. ɪf oʊnli ði ɪn wəd lɛɾ ɪm ɡɛɾ əweɪ.

Logain could do "things," and the way Bartim's eyes shifted and his tongue darted across his lips made it clear what he meant. He had seen the last false Dragon, two years ago, when he was paraded through the countryside, but that was just some fellow who thought he could make himself a king. There had been no need for Aes Sedai, that time. Soldiers had had him chained up on a wagon. A sullen-looking fellow who moaned in the middle of the wagonbed, covering his head with his arms whenever people threw stones or poked him with sticks. There had been a lot of that, and the soldiers had done nothing to stop it, as long as they did not kill the fellow. Best to let the people see he was nothing special after all. He could not do "things." This Logain would be something to see, though. Something for Bartim to tell his grandchildren about. If only the inn would let him get away.

ɹænd lɪsənd wɪð ən ɪntʃɹəs ðət dɪd nɑɾ əv tə bi feɪkt. wən pdən feɪn hæd bɹɔt wɝd tə ɛmənz fild ʌv ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən, ə mæn æktʃəli  wildɪŋ ðə paʊɝ, ɪt hæd bɪn ðə bɪɡəs nuz tə kʌm ɪndə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɪn jɪɹz. wʌt hæd hæpən sɪns hæd pʊʃt ɪt tə ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪnd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ pipəl wəd bi tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt fəɹ jɪɹz, ən tɛlɪŋ ðɛɹ ɡɹæntʃɪlʒɹən əbaʊt, tu. bɑɹɾɪm wəd pɹɑbli tɛl ɪz ðəɾ i hæd sin lɑɡən wɛðɝ i dɪɾ əɹ nɑt. noʊbɑdi wəɾ ɛvɝ θɪŋk wʌt hæpən tə səm vɪlədʒ foʊk fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɑz wɝθ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, nɑɾ ənlɛs ðeɪ wɝ tu ɹɪvɝz pipəl ðɛmsɛlvz.

Rand listened with an interest that did not have to be faked. When Padan Fain had brought word to Emond's Field of a false Dragon, a man actually wielding the Power, it had been the biggest news to come into the Two Rivers in years. What had happened since had pushed it to the back of his mind, but it was still the sort of thing people would be talking about for years, and telling their grandchildren about, too. Bartim would probably tell his that he had seen Logain whether he did or not. Nobody would ever think what happened to some village folk from the Two Rivers was worth talking about, not unless they were Two Rivers people themselves.

"ðæt," tɑm sɛd, "wʊd bi sʌmθɪŋ tə meɪk ə stɔɹi ʌv, ə stɔɹi ðeɪd tɛl fəɹ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz. aɪ wɪʃ aɪ hæd bɪn ðɛɹ." hi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ɪt wɑz ðə sɪmpəl tʃɹuθ, ən ɹænd θɔɾ ɪt ɹɪli wɑz. "aɪ maɪt tʃɹaɪ tə si hɪm ɛniweɪ. jə dɪdn seɪ wʌt ɹut ðeɪ wɝ teɪkɪŋ. pɝhæps ðəɹ ɑɹ səm ʌðɝ tʃɹævəlɝz ɝaʊnd? ðeɪ maɪɾ əv hɝd ðə ɹut."

"That," Thom said, "would be something to make a story of, a story they'd tell for a thousand years. I wish I had been there." He sounded as if it was the simple truth, and Rand thought it really was. "I might try to see him anyway. You didn't say what route they were taking. Perhaps there are some other travelers around? They might have heard the route."

bɑɹɾɪm weɪvd ə ɡɹʌbi hæn dɪsmɪsɪvli. "nɔɹθ, ðæts ɔl ɛnibəɾi noʊz ɝaʊn hɪɹ. jə wɑnə si hɪm, ɡoʊ tə keɪɛmlɪn. ðæts ɔl aɪ noʊ, ən ɪf ðɛɹz ɛniθɪŋ tə noʊ ɪn waɪtbɹɪdʒ, aɪ noʊ ɪt."

Bartim waved a grubby hand dismissively. "North, that's all anybody knows around here. You want to see him, go to Caemlyn. That's all I know, and if there's anything to know in Whitebridge, I know it."

"noʊ daʊt jə du," tɑm sɛd smuðli. "aɪ ɪkspɛkt ə lɑɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz pæsɪŋ θɹu stɑp hɪɹ. jəɹ saɪn kɑt maɪ aɪ fɹəm ðə fʊɾ ə ðə waɪt bɹɪdʒ."

"No doubt you do," Thom said smoothly. "I expect a lot of strangers passing through stop here. Your sign caught my eye from the foot of the White Bridge."

"nɑt dʒʌs fɹəm ðə wɛst, əl əv jə noʊ. tu deɪz əɡoʊ ðəɹ wɑz ə fɛloʊ ɪn hɪɹ, ən ɪliɑnɝ, wɪð ə pɹɑkləmeɪʃən ɔl dʌn ʌp wɪð silz ən ɹɪbənz. ɹɛɾ ɪt ɹaɪɾ aʊt ðəɹ ɪn ðə skwɛɹ. sɛd hiz teɪkɪŋ ɪɾ ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst, meɪbi ivən tə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, ɪf ðə pæsəz ɑɹ oʊpən. sɛd ðeɪv sɛn mɛn tə ɹiɾ ɪɾ ɪn ɛvɹi læn ɪn ðə wɝld." ði ɪnkipɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst. aɪ hɪɹ ðəɹ kʌvɝd wɪð fɑɡ ɔl ðə jɪɹ ɹaʊnd, ən ðɛɹz θɪŋz ɪn ðə fɑɡ wɪl stʃɹɪp ðə flɛʃ ɔf jəɹ boʊnz bɪfɔɹ jə kən ɹʌn." mæt snɪkɝd, ɝnɪŋ ə ʃɑɹp lʊk fɹəm bɑɹɾɪm.

"Not just from the west, I'll have you know. Two days ago there was a fellow in here, an Illianer, with a proclamation all done up with seals and ribbons. Read it right out there in the square. Said he's taking it all the way to the Mountains of Mist, maybe even to the Aryth Ocean, if the passes are open. Said they've sent men to read it in every land in the world." The innkeeper shook his head. "The Mountains of Mist. I hear they're covered with fog all the year round, and there's things in the fog will strip the flesh off your bones before you can run." Mat snickered, earning a sharp look from Bartim.

tɑm lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪntɛnli. "wʌt dɪd ðə pɹɑkləmeɪʃən seɪ?"

Thom leaned forward intently. "What did the proclamation say?"

"waɪ, ðə hʌn fəɹ ðə hɔɹn, ʌv kɔɹs," bɑɹɾɪm ɪkskleɪmd. "dɪdn aɪ seɪ ðæt? ði ɪliɑnɝz ɑɹ kɔlɪŋ ɑn ɛvɹibɑɾi əz wɪl swɛɹ ðɛɹ laɪvz tə ðə hʌn tə ɡæðɝ ɪn ɪljən. kən jə ɪmædʒən ðæt? swɛɹɪŋ jəɹ laɪf tə ə lɛdʒənd? aɪ səpoʊz ðəl faɪn səm fulz. ðɛɹz ɔlweɪz fulz ɝaʊnd. ðɪs fɛloʊ kleɪm ði ɛn ə ðə wɝld ɪz kʌmɪŋ. ðə læs bæɾəl wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn." hi tʃʌkəld, bʌɾ ɪt hæɾ ə hɑloʊ saʊnd, ə mæn læfɪŋ tə kənvɪns hɪmsɛlf sʌmθɪŋ ɹɪli wɑz wɝθ læfɪŋ æt. "ɡɛs ðeɪ θɪŋk ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ əz tə bi faʊn bɪfɔɹ ɪt hæpənz. naʊ wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ə ðæt?" hi tʃuɾ ə nʌkəl pɛnsɪvli fəɹ ə mɪnət. "kɔɹs, aɪ doʊnt noʊ əz aɪ kəɾ ɑɹɡju wɪð əm æftɝ ðɪs wɪntɝ. ðə wɪntɝ, ən ðɪs fɛloʊ lɑɡən, ən ðoʊz ʌðɝ tu bɪfɔɹ, əz wɛl. waɪ ɔl ðiz fɛloʊz ðə læs fju jɪɹz kleɪmɪŋ tə bi ðə dʒɹæɡən? ən ðə wɪntɝ. mʌs min sʌmθɪŋ. wʌt dʒju θɪŋk?"

"Why, the hunt for the Horn, of course," Bartim exclaimed. "Didn't I say that? The Illianers are calling on everybody as will swear their lives to the hunt to gather in Illian. Can you imagine that? Swearing your life to a legend? I suppose they'll find some fools. There's always fools around. This fellow claimed the end of the world is coming. The last battle with the Dark One." He chuckled, but it had a hollow sound, a man laughing to convince himself something really was worth laughing at. "Guess they think the Horn of Valere has to be found before it happens. Now what do you think of that?" He chewed a knuckle pensively for a minute. "Course, I don't know as I could argue with them after this winter. The winter, and this fellow Logain, and those other two before, as well. Why all these fellows the last few years claiming to be the Dragon? And the winter. Must mean something. What do you think?"

tɑm dɪd nɑt sim tə hɪɹ hɪm. ɪn ə sɑf vɔɪs ðə ɡlimən bɪɡæn tə ɹəsaɪt tə hɪmsɛlf.

Thom did not seem to hear him. In a soft voice the gleeman began to recite to himself.

"ɪn ðə læst, lɔɹn faɪt 'ɡeɪns ðə fɔl ə lɔŋ naɪt, ðə maʊntənz stænd ɡɑɹd, ən ðə dɛd ʃæl bi wɔɹd, fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪv ɪz noʊ bɑɹ tə maɪ kɔl."

"In the last, lorn fight 'gainst the fall of long night, the mountains stand guard, and the dead shall be ward, for the grave is no bar to my call."

"ðæts ɪt." bɑɹɾɪm ɡɹɪn əz ɪf i kəɾ ɔlɹɛɾi si ðə kɹaʊdz hændɪŋ ɪm ðɛɹ mʌni waɪl ðeɪ lɪsən tə tɑm. "ðæts ɪt. ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn. jə tɛl ðət wʌn, ən ðəl bi hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɹæftɝz ɪn hɪɹ. ɛvɹibɑɾiz hɝɾ əbaʊt ðə pɹɑkləmeɪʃən."

"That's it." Bartim grinned as if he could already see the crowds handing him their money while they listened to Thom. "That's it. The Great Hunt of the Horn. You tell that one, and they'll be hanging from the rafters in here. Everybody's heard about the proclamation."

tɑm stɪl sim tə bi ə θaʊzən maɪlz əweɪ, soʊ ɹænd sɛd, "wɝ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ səm fɹɛnz u wɝ kʌmɪŋ ðɪs weɪ. fɹəm ðə wɛst. hæv ðəɹ bɪn mɛni stʃɹeɪnʒɝz pæsɪŋ θɹu ɪn ðə læst wik əɹ tu?"

Thom still seemed to be a thousand miles away, so Rand said, "We're looking for some friends who were coming this way. From the west. Have there been many strangers passing through in the last week or two?"

"sʌm," bɑɹɾɪm sɛd sloʊli. "ðɛɹz ɔlweɪz sʌm, fɹəm ist ən wɛs boʊθ." hi lʊkt əɾ itʃ ə ðɛm ɪn tɝn, sʌɾənli wɛɹi. "wʌt də ðeɪ lʊk laɪk, ðiz fɹɛnz ə jʊɹz?"

"Some," Bartim said slowly. "There's always some, from east and west both." He looked at each of them in turn, suddenly wary. "What do they look like, these friends of yours?"

ɹænd oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, bʌt tɑm, əbɹʌpli bæk fɹəm wɛɹɛvɝ i hæd bɪn, ɡeɪv ɪm ə ʃɑɹp, saɪlənsɪŋ lʊk. wɪð ən ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd saɪ ðə ɡlimən tɝn tə ði ɪnkipɝ. "tu mɛn ən θɹi wɪmən," hi sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli. "ðeɪ meɪ bi təɡɛðɝ, əɹ meɪbi nɑt." hi ɡeɪv θʌmneɪl skɛtʃəz, peɪntɪŋ itʃ wʌn ɪn dʒʌst ə fju wɝdz, ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛniwʌn u hæd sin əm tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz wɪθaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ əweɪ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊɾ u ðeɪ wɝ.

Rand opened his mouth, but Thom, abruptly back from wherever he had been, gave him a sharp, silencing look. With an exasperated sigh the gleeman turned to the innkeeper. "Two men and three women," he said reluctantly. "They may be together, or maybe not." He gave thumbnail sketches, painting each one in just a few words, enough for anyone who had seen them to recognize without giving away anything about who they were.

bɑɹɾɪm ɹʌbd wʌn hæn oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd, dɪsɹeɪnʒɪŋ ɪz θɪnɪŋ hɛɹ, ən stʊɾ ʌp sloʊli. "fɝɡɛɾ əbaʊt pɝfɔɹmɪŋ hɪɹ, ɡlimən. ɪn fækt, aɪɾ əpɹiʃieɪɾ ɪɾ ɪf jə dʒɹæŋk jəɹ waɪn ən lɛft. liv waɪtbɹɪdʒ, ɪf jəɹ smɑɹt."

Bartim rubbed one hand over his head, disarranging his thinning hair, and stood up slowly. "Forget about performing here, gleeman. In fact, I'd appreciate it if you drank your wine and left. Leave Whitebridge, if you're smart."

"sʌmwʌn ɛls əz bɪn æskɪŋ æftɝ ðɛm?" tɑm tʊk ə dʒɹɪŋk, əz ɪf ði ænsɝ wɝ ðə list ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld, ən ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət ði ɪnkipɝ. "hu wəd ðət bi?"

"Someone else has been asking after them?" Thom took a drink, as if the answer were the least important thing in the world, and raised an eyebrow at the innkeeper. "Who would that be?"

bɑɹɾɪm skɹʌbd ɪz hæn θɹu hɪz hɛɹ əɡɛn ən ʃɪftəɾ ɪz fiɾ ɑn ðə pɔɪn ʌv wɔkɪŋ əweɪ, ðən nɑɾəd tə hɪmsɛlf. "əbaʊɾ ə wik əɡoʊ, əz nɪɹ əz aɪ kən seɪ, ə wizəli fɛloʊ keɪm oʊvɝ ðə bɹɪdʒ. kɹeɪzi, ɛvɹibɑɾi θɔt. ɔlweɪz tɔkɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, nɛvɝ stɑp muvɪŋ ivən wən i wɑz stændɪŋ stɪl. æskt əbaʊt ðə seɪm pipəl . . . səm ə ðɛm. hi æsk laɪk ɪt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt, ðən æktəd laɪk i dɪdn kɛɹ wʌt ði ænsɝ wɑz. hæf ðə taɪm i wɑz seɪɪŋ əz i hæd tə weɪt hɪɹ fəɹ ðɛm, ən ði ʌðɝ hæf əz i hæd tə ɡoʊ ɑn, hi wɑz ɪn ə hɝi. wʌn mɪnəɾ i wɑz waɪnɪŋ ən bɛɡɪŋ, ðə nɛks meɪkɪŋ dɪmænz laɪk ə kɪŋ. nɪɹ ɡɑt hɪmsɛlf ə θɹæʃɪŋ ə taɪm əɹ tu, kɹeɪzi əɹ nɑt. ðə wɑtʃ ɔlmoʊs tʊk ɪm ɪn kʌstəɾi fəɹ ɪz oʊn seɪfti. hi wɛn ɔf təwɔɹd keɪɛmlɪn ðət seɪm deɪ, tɔkɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf ən kɹaɪɪŋ. kɹeɪzi, laɪk aɪ sɛd."

Bartim scrubbed his hand through his hair again and shifted his feet on the point of walking away, then nodded to himself. "About a week ago, as near as I can say, a weaselly fellow came over the bridge. Crazy, everybody thought. Always talking to himself, never stopped moving even when he was standing still. Asked about the same people . . . some of them. He asked like it was important, then acted like he didn't care what the answer was. Half the time he was saying as he had to wait here for them, and the other half as he had to go on, he was in a hurry. One minute he was whining and begging, the next making demands like a king. Near got himself a thrashing a time or two, crazy or not. The Watch almost took him in custody for his own safety. He went off toward Caemlyn that same day, talking to himself and crying. Crazy, like I said."

ɹænd lʊkt ət tɑm ən mæt kwɛstʃənɪŋli, ən ðeɪ boʊθ ʃʊk ðɛɹ hɛdz. ɪf ðɪs wizəli fɛloʊ wɑz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ðɛm, hi wɑz stɪl noʊbɑdi ðeɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd.

Rand looked at Thom and Mat questioningly, and they both shook their heads. If this weaselly fellow was looking for them, he was still nobody they recognized.

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm pipəl i wɑntəd?" ɹænd æskt.

"Are you sure it was the same people he wanted?" Rand asked.

"sʌm ə ðɛm. ðə faɪɾɪŋ mæn, ən ðə wʊmən ɪn sɪlk. bʌɾ ɪt wɑzn əm əz i kɛɹɾ əbaʊt. ɪt wɑz θɹi kʌntʃɹi bɔɪz." hɪz aɪz slɪɾ əkɹɔs ɹænd ən mæt ən əweɪ əɡɛn soʊ fæs ðət ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf i hæd ɹɪli sin ðə lʊk əɹ ɪmædʒən ɪt. "hi wɑz dɛspɹɪt tə faɪn ðɛm. bʌt kɹeɪzi, laɪk aɪ sɛd."

"Some of them. The fighting man, and the woman in silk. But it wasn't them as he cared about. It was three country boys." His eyes slid across Rand and Mat and away again so fast that Rand was not sure if he had really seen the look or imagined it. "He was desperate to find them. But crazy, like I said."

ɹænd ʃɪvɝd, ən wʌndɝɾ u ðə kɹeɪzi mæn kəd bi, ən waɪ hi wɑz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ðɛm. eɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnd? wəd bælzəmən juz ə mædmæn?

Rand shivered, and wondered who the crazy man could be, and why he was looking for them. A Darkfriend? Would Ba'alzamon use a madman?

"hi wɑz kɹeɪzi, bʌt ði ʌðɝ wʌn. . . ." bɑɹɾɪmz aɪz ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli, ən ɪz tʌŋ ɹæn oʊvɝ ɪz lɪps əz ɪf i kəd nɑt faɪn ɪnʌf spɪt tə mɔɪsən ðɛm. "nɛks deɪ . . . nɛks deɪ ði ʌðɝ wʌn keɪm fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm." hi fɛl saɪlənt.

"He was crazy, but the other one. . . ." Bartim's eyes shifted uneasily, and his tongue ran over his lips as if he could not find enough spit to moisten them. "Next day . . . next day the other one came for the first time." He fell silent.

"ði ʌðɝ wʌn?" tɑm pɹɑmptəd faɪnəli.

"The other one?" Thom prompted finally.

bɑɹɾɪm lʊkt ɝaʊnd, ɔlðoʊ ðɛɹ saɪɾ ə ðə dɪvaɪɾəd ɹum wɑz stɪl ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ðɛm. hi ivən ɹeɪzd ʌp ɑn ɪz toʊz ən lʊkt oʊvɝ ðə loʊ wɔl. wən i faɪnəli spoʊk, ɪt wɑz ɪn ə wɪspɝd ɹʌʃ.

Bartim looked around, although their side of the divided room was still empty except for them. He even raised up on his toes and looked over the low wall. When he finally spoke, it was in a whispered rush.

"ɔl ɪn blæk i ɪz. kips ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk pʊld ʌp soʊ jə kæn si hɪz feɪs, bʌt jə kən fil ɪm lʊkɪŋ ət ju, fil ɪt laɪk ən aɪsɪkəl ʃʌvd ɪndə jəɹ spaɪn. hi . . . hi spoʊk tə mi." hi flɪntʃt ən stɑp tə tʃu əɾ ɪz lɪp bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. "saʊndəd laɪk ə sneɪk kɹɔlɪŋ θɹu dɛd livz. fɛɹ tɝn maɪ stʌmək tə aɪs. ɛvɹi taɪm əz i kʌmz bæk, hi æsks ðə seɪm kwɛstʃənz. seɪm kwɛstʃənz ðə kɹeɪzi mæn æskt. noʊbɑdi ɛvɝ siz ɪm kʌmɪŋ - hiz dʒʌs ðəɹ ɔl ʌv ə sʌɾən, deɪ əɹ naɪt, fɹizɪŋ jə wɛɹ jə stænd. pipəl ɑɹ stɑɹɾɪŋ tə lʊk oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz. wɝst ʌv ɪɾ ɪz, ðə ɡəttɛndɝz kleɪm əz hiz nɛvɝ pæs θɹu ɛni ʌv ðə ɡeɪts, kʌmɪŋ əɹ ɡoʊɪŋ."

"All in black he is. Keeps the hood of his cloak pulled up so you can't see his face, but you can feel him looking at you, feel it like an icicle shoved into your spine. He . . . he spoke to me." He flinched and stopped to chew at his lip before going on. "Sounded like a snake crawling through dead leaves. Fair turned my stomach to ice. Every time as he comes back, he asks the same questions. Same questions the crazy man asked. Nobody ever sees him coming - he's just there all of a sudden, day or night, freezing you where you stand. People are starting to look over their shoulders. Worst of it is, the gatetenders claim as he's never passed through any of the gates, coming or going."

ɹænd wɝkt ət kipɪŋ ɪz feɪs blæŋk; hi klɛntʃt ɪz dʒɔ əntɪl ɪz tiθ ætʃt. mæt skaʊld, ən tɑm stʌɾid ɪz waɪn. ðə wɝd nʌn ə ðɛm wɑntəd tə seɪ hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ bɪtwin ðɛm. mɹdʒɹɑl.

Rand worked at keeping his face blank; he clenched his jaw until his teeth ached. Mat scowled, and Thom studied his wine. The word none of them wanted to say hung in the air between them. Myrddraal.

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪf aɪ ɛvɝ mɛɾ ɛniwʌn laɪk ðæt," tɑm sɛɾ æftɝ ə mɪnət.

"I think I'd remember if I ever met anyone like that," Thom said after a minute.

bɑɹɾɪmz hɛd bɑb fjʊɹiəsli. "bɝn mi, bʌt jə wʊd. laɪts tʃɹuθ, jə wʊd. hi . . . hi wɑns ðə seɪm lɑɾ əz ðə kɹeɪzi mæn, oʊnli hi sɛz əz ðɛɹz ə ɡɝl wɪð ðɛm. ænd" - hi ɡlænst saɪdweɪz ət tɑm -  "æn ə waɪt-hɛɹd ɡlimən."

Bartim's head bobbed furiously. "Burn me, but you would. Light's truth, you would. He . . . he wants the same lot as the crazy man, only he says as there's a girl with them. And" - he glanced sideways at Thom -  "and a white-haired gleeman."

tɑmz aɪbɹaʊz ʃɑɾ ʌp ɪn wʌt ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ wɑz ənfeɪən sɝpɹaɪz. "ə waɪt-hɛɹd ɡlimən? wɛl, aɪm hɑɹdli ði oʊnli ɡlimən ɪn ðə wɝld wɪð ə lɪɾəl eɪdʒ ɑn hɪm. aɪ əʃʊɹ ju, aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðɪs fɛloʊ, ən i kən əv noʊ ɹizən tə bi lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mi."

Thom's eyebrows shot up in what Rand was sure was unfeigned surprise. "A white-haired gleeman? Well, I'm hardly the only gleeman in the world with a little age on him. I assure you, I don't know this fellow, and he can have no reason to be looking for me."

"ðæts əz meɪ bi," bɑɹɾɪm sɛd ɡlʌmli. "hi dɪdn seɪ ɪɾ ɪn soʊ mɛni wɝdz, bʌɾ aɪ ɡɑt ði ɪmpɹɛʃən əz i wəd bi vɛɹi dɪsplizd wɪð ɛniwʌn əz tʃɹaɪd tə hɛlp ðiz pipəl, əɹ tʃɹaɪd tə haɪɾ əm fɹəm hɪm. ɛniweɪ, əl tɛl jə wʌɾ aɪ toʊl hɪm. aɪ hævən sin ɛni ʌv ðɛm, nɔɹ hɝd tɛl ə ðɛm, ən ðæts ðə tʃɹuθ. nɑɾ ɛni ʌv ðɛm," hi fɪnɪʃt pɔɪntɪdli. əbɹʌpli hi slæp tɑmz mʌni daʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "dʒʌs fɪnɪʃ jəɹ waɪn ən ɡoʊ. ɔl ɹaɪt? ɔl ɹaɪt?" ən i tʃɹʌndəld əweɪ əz fæst əz i kʊd, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.

"That's as may be," Bartim said glumly. "He didn't say it in so many words, but I got the impression as he would be very displeased with anyone as tried to help these people, or tried to hide them from him. Anyway, I'll tell you what I told him. I haven't seen any of them, nor heard tell of them, and that's the truth. Not any of them," he finished pointedly. Abruptly he slapped Thom's money down on the table. "Just finish your wine and go. All right? All right?" And he trundled away as fast as he could, looking over his shoulder.

"eɪ feɪd," mæt bɹiðd wən ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz ɡɔn. "aɪ ʃʊɾə noʊn ðeɪd bi lʊkɪŋ fəɹ əs hɪɹ."

"A Fade," Mat breathed when the innkeeper was gone. "I should have known they'd be looking for us here."

"æn hɪl bi bæk," tɑm sɛd, linɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə teɪbəl ən loʊɝɪŋ ɪz vɔɪs. "aɪ seɪ wi snik bæk tə ðə boʊɾ ən teɪk kæptən doʊmən ʌp ɑn ɪz ɔfɝ. ðə hʌnt wɪl sɛntɝ ɑn ðə ɹoʊd tə keɪɛmlɪn waɪl wɝ ɑn əɹ weɪ tə ɪljən, ə θaʊzən maɪlz fɹəm wɛɹ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl ɪkspɛkt ʌs."

"And he'll be back," Thom said, leaning across the table and lowering his voice. "I say we sneak back to the boat and take Captain Domon up on his offer. The hunt will center on the road to Caemlyn while we're on our way to Illian, a thousand miles from where the Myrddraal expect us."

"noʊ," ɹænd sɛd fɝmli. "wi weɪt fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn ən ði ʌðɝz ɪn waɪtbɹɪdʒ, əɹ wi ɡoʊ ɑn tə keɪɛmlɪn. wʌn əɹ ði ʌðɝ, tɑm. ðæts wʌt wi dɪsaɪɾɪd."

"No," Rand said firmly. "We wait for Moiraine and the others in Whitebridge, or we go on to Caemlyn. One or the other, Thom. That's what we decided."

"ðæts kɹeɪzd, bɔɪ. θɪŋz əv tʃeɪnʒd. jə lɪsən tə mi. noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðɪs ɪnkipɝ sɛz, wən ə mɹdʒɹɑl stɛɹz ət hɪm, hɪl tɛl ɔl əbaʊɾ əs daʊn tə wʌt wi hæd tə dʒɹɪŋk ən haʊ mʌtʃ dʌst wi hæɾ ɑn əɹ buts." ɹænd ʃɪvɝd, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðə feɪdz aɪləs stɛɹ. "æz fəɹ keɪɛmlɪn. . . . jə θɪŋk ðə hæfmən doʊnt noʊ jə wɑnə ɡɛt tə tɑɹ vəlɑn? ɪts ə ɡʊd taɪm tə bi ɑn ə boʊt hɛɾəd saʊθ."

"That's crazed, boy. Things have changed. You listen to me. No matter what this innkeeper says, when a Myrddraal stares at him, he'll tell all about us down to what we had to drink and how much dust we had on our boots." Rand shivered, remembering the Fade's eyeless stare. "As for Caemlyn. . . . You think the Halfmen don't know you want to get to Tar Valon? It's a good time to be on a boat headed south."

"noʊ, tɑm." ɹænd hæd tə fɔɹs ðə wɝdz aʊt, θɪŋkɪŋ ə biɪŋ ə θaʊzən maɪlz fɹəm wɛɹ ðə feɪdz wɝ lʊkɪŋ, bʌɾ i tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən mænədʒ tə fɝm ɪz vɔɪs. "noʊ."

"No, Thom." Rand had to force the words out, thinking of being a thousand miles from where the Fades were looking, but he took a deep breath and managed to firm his voice. "No."

"θɪŋk, bɔɪ. ɪljən! ðəɹ ɪzən ə ɡɹændɝ sɪɾi ɑn ðə feɪs ə ði ɝθ. ən ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn! ðəɹ hæzən bɪn ə hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn ɪn nɪɹ fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ə hoʊl nu saɪkəl ə stɔɹiz weɪɾɪŋ tə bi meɪd. dʒʌs θɪŋk. jə nɛvɝ dʒɹimd ʌv ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ɪt. baɪ ðə taɪm ðə mɹdʒɹɑl fɪɡjɝ aʊt wɛɹ juv ɡɔn tə, jəl bi oʊld ən ɡɹeɪ ən soʊ taɪɝɾ ʌv wɑtʃɪŋ jəɹ ɡɹæntʃɪlʒɹən jə woʊn kɛɹ ɪf ðeɪ də faɪn ju."

"Think, boy. Illian! There isn't a grander city on the face of the earth. And the Great Hunt of the Horn! There hasn't been a Hunt of the Horn in near four hundred years. A whole new cycle of stories waiting to be made. Just think. You never dreamed of anything like it. By the time the Myrddraal figure out where you've gone to, you'll be old and gray and so tired of watching your grandchildren you won't care if they do find you."

ɹændz feɪs tʊk ɑn ə stʌbɝn sɛt. "haʊ mɛni taɪmz də aɪ hæv tə seɪ noʊ? ðəl faɪn əs wɛɹɛvɝ wi ɡoʊ. ðɛɹəd bi feɪdz weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ɪljən, tu. ən haʊ də wi ɪskeɪp ðə dʒɹimz? aɪ wɑnə noʊ wʌts hæpənɪŋ tə mi, tɑm, ən waɪ. aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn ɪf aɪ kæn; wɪθaʊɾ əɹ ɪf aɪ hæv tə. əloʊn, ɪf aɪ hæv tə. aɪ nid tə noʊ."

Rand's face took on a stubborn set. "How many times do I have to say no? They'll find us wherever we go. There'd be Fades waiting in Illian, too. And how do we escape the dreams? I want to know what's happening to me, Thom, and why. I'm going to Tar Valon. With Moiraine if I can; without her if I have to. Alone, if I have to. I need to know."

"bʌɾ ɪljən, bɔɪ! ən ə seɪf weɪ aʊt, daʊnɹɪvɝ waɪl ðəɹ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ jə ɪn ənʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, ə dʒɹim kæn hɝt ju."

"But Illian, boy! And a safe way out, downriver while they're looking for you in another direction. Blood and ashes, a dream can't hurt you."

ɹænd kɛp saɪlənt. ə dʒɹim kæn hɝt? də dʒɹim θɔɹnz dʒɹɔ ɹil blʌd? hi ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt i hæd toʊl tɑm əbaʊt ðət dʒɹim, tu. dʒju dɛɹ tɛl ɛnibəɾi? bælzəmən ɪz ɪn jəɹ dʒɹimz, bʌt wʌts bɪtwin dʒɹimɪŋ ən weɪkɪŋ, naʊ? hu dʒju dɛɹ tə tɛl ðət ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪz tʌtʃɪŋ ju?

Rand kept silent. A dream can't hurt? Do dream thorns draw real blood? He almost wished he had told Thom about that dream, too. Do you dare tell anybody? Ba'alzamon is in your dreams, but what's between dreaming and waking, now? Who do you dare to tell that the Dark One is touching you?

tɑm sim tə ʌndɝstænd. ðə ɡlimənz feɪs sɔfənd. "ivən ðoʊz dʒɹimz, læd. ðeɪ ɑɹ stɪl dʒʌs dʒɹimz, ɑɹən ðeɪ? fəɹ ðə laɪts seɪk, mæt, tɔk tə hɪm. aɪ noʊ jə doʊnt wɑnə ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ət list."

Thom seemed to understand. The gleeman's face softened. "Even those dreams, lad. They are still just dreams, aren't they? For the Light's sake, Mat, talk to him. I know you don't want to go to Tar Valon, at least."

mæts feɪs ɹɛɾənd, hæf ɪmbɛɹəsmən ən hæf æŋɡɝ. hi əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət ɹænd ən skaʊld ət tɑm ɪnstɛd. "waɪ ɑɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ tə ɔl ðɪs fʌs ən bɑðɝ? jə wɑnə ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə boʊt? ɡoʊ bæk tə ðə boʊt. wɪl teɪk kɛɹ ʌv aʊɝsɛlvz."

Mat's face reddened, half embarrassment and half anger. He avoided looking at Rand and scowled at Thom instead. "Why are you going to all this fuss and bother? You want to go back to the boat? Go back to the boat. We'll take care of ourselves."

ðə ɡlimənz θɪn ʃoʊldɝz ʃʊk wɪð saɪlən læftɝ, bʌɾ ɪz vɔɪs wɑz æŋɡɝ taɪt. "ju θɪŋk jə noʊ ɪnʌf əbaʊt mɹdʒɹɑl tə ɪskeɪp baɪ jɝsɛlf, də ju? jəɹ ɹɛɾi tə wɔk ɪndə tɑɹ vəlɑn əloʊn ən hæn jɝsɛlf oʊvɝ tə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit? kən jə ivən tɛl wʌn ədʒɑ fɹəm ənʌðɝ? ðə laɪt bɝn mi, bɔɪ, ɪf jə θɪŋk jə kən ivən ɡɛt tə tɑɹ vəlɑn əloʊn, jə tɛl mi tə ɡoʊ."

The gleeman's thin shoulders shook with silent laughter, but his voice was anger tight. "You think you know enough about Myrddraal to escape by yourself, do you? You're ready to walk into Tar Valon alone and hand yourself over to the Amyrlin Seat? Can you even tell one Ajah from another? The Light burn me, boy, if you think you can even get to Tar Valon alone, you tell me to go."

"ɡoʊ," mæt ɡɹaʊld, slaɪɾɪŋ ə hæn ʌndɝ ɪz kloʊk. ɹænd ɹilaɪzd wɪð ə ʃɑk ðəɾ i wɑz ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, meɪbi ivən ɹɛɾi tə juz ɪt.

"Go," Mat growled, sliding a hand under his cloak. Rand realized with a shock that he was gripping the dagger from Shadar Logoth, maybe even ready to use it.

ɹɔkəs læftɝ bɹoʊk aʊɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə loʊ wɔl dɪvaɪɾɪŋ ðə ɹum, ən ə skɔɹnfəl vɔɪs spoʊk ʌp laʊdli.

Raucous laughter broke out on the other side of the low wall dividing the room, and a scornful voice spoke up loudly.

"tʃɹɑləks? pʊɾ ɑn ə ɡlimənz kloʊk, mæn! jəɹ dʒɹʌŋk! tʃɹɑləks! bɔɹɾɝlənd feɪbəlz!"

"Trollocs? Put on a gleeman's cloak, man! You're drunk! Trollocs! Borderland fables!"

ðə wɝdz daʊst æŋɡɝ laɪk ə pɑɾ ə koʊld wɔɾɝ. ivən mæt hæf tɝn tə ðə wɔl, aɪz waɪɾənɪŋ.

The words doused anger like a pot of cold water. Even Mat half turned to the wall, eyes widening.

ɹænd stʊd dʒʌst ɪnʌf tə si oʊvɝ ðə wɔl, ðən dʌk bæk daʊn əɡɛn wɪð ə sɪŋkɪŋ filɪŋ ɪn ɪz stʌmək. flɔɹən dʒɛlb sæɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə wɔl, ət ðə teɪbəl ɪn ðə bæk wɪð ðə tu mɛn u hæd bɪn ðəɹ wən ðeɪ keɪm ɪn. ðeɪ wɝ læfɪŋ ət hɪm, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ lɪsnɪŋ. bɑɹɾɪm wɑz waɪpɪŋ ə teɪbəl ðət bædli niɾəd ɪt, nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət dʒɛlb ən ðə tu mɛn, bʌɾ i wɑz lɪsnɪŋ, tu, skɹʌbɪŋ wʌn spɑɾ oʊvɝ ən oʊvɝ wɪð ɪz taʊəl ən linɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əm əntɪl i simd ɔlmoʊst ɹɛɾi tə fɔl oʊvɝ.

Rand stood just enough to see over the wall, then ducked back down again with a sinking feeling in his stomach. Floran Gelb sat on the other side of the wall, at the table in the back with the two men who had been there when they came in. They were laughing at him, but they were listening. Bartim was wiping a table that badly needed it, not looking at Gelb and the two men, but he was listening, too, scrubbing one spot over and over with his towel and leaning toward them until he seemed almost ready to fall over.

"dʒɛlb," ɹænd wɪspɝɾ əz i dʒɹɑp bæk ɪndə hɪz tʃɛɹ, ən ði ʌðɝz tɛnst. tɑm swɪfli stʌɾid ðɛɹ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹum.

"Gelb," Rand whispered as he dropped back into his chair, and the others tensed. Thom swiftly studied their side of the room.

ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə wɔl ðə sɛkən mænz vɔɪs tʃaɪmd ɪn. "noʊ, noʊ, ðəɹ juz tə bi tʃɹɑləks. bʌt ðeɪ kɪld əm ɔl ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz."

On the other side of the wall the second man's voice chimed in. "No, no, there used to be Trollocs. But they killed them all in the Trolloc Wars."

"bɔɹɾɝlənd feɪbəlz!" ðə fɝs mæn ɹɪpiɾɪd.

"Borderland fables!" the first man repeated.

"ɪts tʃɹu, aɪ tɛl ju," dʒɛlb pɹətɛstəd laʊdli. "aɪv bɪn ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. aɪv sin tʃɹɑləks, ən ðiz wɝ tʃɹɑləks əz ʃʊɹ əz aɪm sɪɾɪŋ hɪɹ. ðoʊz θɹi kleɪm ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ tʃeɪsɪŋ ðɛm, bʌɾ aɪ noʊ bɛɾɝ. ðæts waɪ aɪ wʊdn steɪ ɑn ðə spɹeɪ. aɪv hæd maɪ səspɪʃənz əbaʊt beɪl doʊmən fəɹ səm taɪm, bʌt ðoʊz θɹi ɑɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz fəɹ ʃʊɹ. aɪ tɛl ju. . . ." læftɝ ən kɔɹs dʒoʊks dʒɹaʊn aʊt ðə ɹɛst ʌv wʌt dʒɛlb hæd tə seɪ.

"It's true, I tell you," Gelb protested loudly. "I've been in the Borderlands. I've seen Trollocs, and these were Trollocs as sure as I'm sitting here. Those three claimed the Trollocs were chasing them, but I know better. That's why I wouldn't stay on the Spray. I've had my suspicions about Bayle Domon for some time, but those three are Darkfriends for sure. I tell you. . . ." Laughter and coarse jokes drowned out the rest of what Gelb had to say.

haʊ lɔŋ, ɹænd wʌndɝd, bɪfɔɹ ði ɪnkipɝ hɝɾ ə dɪskɹɪpʃən ʌv "ðoʊz θɹi"? ɪf i hæd nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. ɪf i dɪd nɑt dʒʌs lip tə ðə θɹi stʃɹeɪnʒɝz i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sin. ði oʊnli dɔɹ fɹəm ðɛɹ hæf ə ðə kɑmən ɹum wəd teɪk əm ɹaɪt pæs dʒɛlbz teɪbəl.

How long, Rand wondered, before the innkeeper heard a description of "those three"? If he had not already. If he did not just leap to the three strangers he had already seen. The only door from their half of the common room would take them right past Gelb's table.

"meɪbi ðə boʊɾ ɪzən sətʃ ə bæɾ aɪdiə," mæt mʌɾɝd, bʌt tɑm ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

"Maybe the boat isn't such a bad idea," Mat muttered, but Thom shook his head.

"nɑɾ ɛnimɔɹ." ðə ɡlimən spoʊk sɔfli ən fæst. hi pʊld aʊt ðə lɛðɝ pɝs kæptən doʊmən hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ən heɪstəli dɪvaɪɾəd ðə mʌni ɪndə θɹi paɪlz. "ðæt stɔɹi wɪl bi ɔl θɹu ðə taʊn ɪn ən aʊɝ, wɛðɝ ɛnibəɾi bɪlivz ɪɾ əɹ nɑt, ən ðə hæfmən kəd hɪɹ ɛni taɪm. doʊmən ɪzən seɪlɪŋ əntɪl təmɑɹoʊ mɔɹnɪŋ. ət bɛs hɪl əv tʃɹɑləks tʃeɪsɪŋ ɪm ɔl ðə weɪ tə ɪljən. wɛl, hiz hæf ɪkspɛktɪŋ ɪt fəɹ səm ɹizən, bʌt ðət woʊn də əs ɛni ɡʊd. ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪt bʌt tə ɹʌn, ən ɹʌn hɑɹd."

"Not anymore." The gleeman spoke softly and fast. He pulled out the leather purse Captain Domon had given him and hastily divided the money into three piles. "That story will be all through the town in an hour, whether anybody believes it or not, and the Halfman could hear any time. Domon isn't sailing until tomorrow morning. At best he'll have Trollocs chasing him all the way to Illian. Well, he's half expecting it for some reason, but that won't do us any good. There's nothing for it but to run, and run hard."

mæt kwɪkli stʌf ðə kɔɪnz tɑm ʃʌvd ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ɪndə hɪz pɑkət. ɹænd pɪkt ɪz paɪl ʌp mɔɹ sloʊli. ðə kɔɪn mɔɪɹeɪn hæd ɡɪvən ɪm wɑz nɑɾ əmʌŋ ðɛm. doʊmən hæd ɡɪvən ən ikwəl weɪɾ ə sɪlvɝ, bʌt ɹænd, fəɹ səm ɹizən i kəd nɑt fæðəm, wɪʃt i hæd ði ɛɛs sədaɪz kɔɪn ɪnstɛd. stʌfɪŋ ðə mʌni ɪn ɪz pɑkət, hi lʊkt ə kwɛstʃən ət ðə ɡlimən.

Mat quickly stuffed the coins Thom shoved in front of him into his pocket. Rand picked his pile up more slowly. The coin Moiraine had given him was not among them. Domon had given an equal weight of silver, but Rand, for some reason he could not fathom, wished he had the Aes Sedai's coin instead. Stuffing the money in his pocket, he looked a question at the gleeman.

"ɪn keɪs wɝ sɛpɝeɪɾəd," tɑm ɪkspleɪnd. "wi pɹɑbli woʊn bi, bʌɾ ɪf ɪt dʌz hæpən . . . wɛl, jə tu wɪl meɪk aʊɾ ɔl ɹaɪt baɪ jʊɹsɛlvz. jəɹ ɡʊd lædz. dʒʌs kip klɪɹ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ, fəɹ jəɹ laɪvz."

"In case we're separated," Thom explained. "We probably won't be, but if it does happen . . . well, you two will make out all right by yourselves. You're good lads. Just keep clear of Aes Sedai, for your lives."

"aɪ θɔt jə wɝ steɪɪŋ wɪð ʌs," ɹænd sɛd.

"I thought you were staying with us," Rand said.

"aɪ æm, bɔɪ. aɪ æm. bʌt ðəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ kloʊs, naʊ, ən ðə laɪɾ oʊnli noʊz. wɛl, noʊ mæɾɝ. ɪɾ ɪzən laɪkli ɛniθɪŋ wɪl hæpən." tɑm pɔzd, lʊkɪŋ ət mæt. "aɪ hoʊp jə noʊ lɔŋɡɝ maɪn mi steɪɪŋ wɪð ju," hi sɛd dʒɹaɪli.

"I am, boy. I am. But they're getting close, now, and the Light only knows. Well, no matter. It isn't likely anything will happen." Thom paused, looking at Mat. "I hope you no longer mind me staying with you," he said dryly.

mæt ʃɹʌɡd. hi aɪɾ itʃ ə ðɛm, ðən ʃɹʌɡd əɡɛn. "aɪm dʒʌst ɑn ɛdʒ. aɪ kæn sim tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ʌv ɪt. ɛvɹi taɪm wi stɑp fəɹ ə bɹɛθ, ðəɹ ðɛɹ, hʌntɪŋ ʌs. aɪ fil laɪk sʌmbɑɾiz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə bæk ə maɪ hɛɾ ɔl ðə taɪm. wʌɾ ɑɹ wi ɡoʊɪŋ tə du?"

Mat shrugged. He eyed each of them, then shrugged again. "I'm just on edge. I can't seem to get rid of it. Every time we stop for a breath, they're there, hunting us. I feel like somebody's staring at the back of my head all the time. What are we going to do?"

ðə læftɝ ɪɹʌptəɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə wɔl, bɹoʊkən əɡɛn baɪ dʒɛlb, tʃɹaɪɪŋ laʊdli tə kənvɪns ðə tu mɛn ðəɾ i wɑz tɛlɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ. haʊ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ, ɹænd wʌndɝd. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ bɑɹɾɪm hæd tə pʊt təɡɛðɝ dʒɛlbz θɹi ən ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm.

The laughter erupted on the other side of the wall, broken again by Gelb, trying loudly to convince the two men that he was telling the truth. How much longer, Rand wondered. Sooner or later Bartim had to put together Gelb's three and the three of them.

tɑm izd ɪz tʃɛɹ ən ɹoʊz, bʌt kɛpt ɪz haɪt kɹaʊtʃt. noʊ wʌn lʊkɪŋ kæʒəwəli təwɔɹd ðə wɔl fɹəm ði ʌðɝ saɪd kəd si hɪm. hi moʊʃən fəɹ əm tə fɑloʊ, wɪspɝɪŋ, "bi vɛɹi kwaɪət."

Thom eased his chair and rose, but kept his height crouched. No one looking casually toward the wall from the other side could see him. He motioned for them to follow, whispering, "Be very quiet."

ðə wɪndoʊz ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs ɑn ðɛɹ saɪɾ ə ðə wɔl lʊkt aʊɾ ɪndə ən æliweɪ. tɑm stʌɾid wʌn ə ðə wɪndoʊz kɛɹfəli bɪfɔɹ dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp dʒʌst ɪnʌf fəɹ əm tə skwiz θɹu. ɪt bɛɹli meɪɾ ə saʊnd, nʌθɪŋ ðət cʊɾə bɪn hɝd θɹi fiɾ əweɪ oʊvɝ ðə læfɪŋ ɑɹɡjəmən ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə loʊ wɔl.

The windows on either side of the fireplace on their side of the wall looked out into an alleyway. Thom studied one of the windows carefully before drawing it up just enough for them to squeeze through. It barely made a sound, nothing that could have been heard three feet away over the laughing argument on the other side of the low wall.

wʌns ɪn ði æli, mæt stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə stʃɹit ɹaɪɾ əweɪ, bʌt tɑm kɑɾ ɪz ɑɹm. "nɑt soʊ fæst," ðə ɡlimən toʊl hɪm. "nɑt tɪl wi noʊ wʌt wɝ duɪŋ." tɑm loʊɝd ðə wɪndoʊ əɡɛn əz mʌtʃ əz i kəd fɹəm aʊtsaɪd, ən tɝn tə stʌɾi ði æli.

Once in the alley, Mat started for the street right away, but Thom caught his arm. "Not so fast," the gleeman told him. "Not till we know what we're doing." Thom lowered the window again as much as he could from outside, and turned to study the alley.

ɹænd fɑloʊd tɑmz aɪz. ɪksɛp fəɹ hæf ə dʌzən ɹeɪn bæɹəlz əɡɛns ði ɪn ən ðə nɛks bɪldɪŋ, ə teɪlɝ ʃɑp, ði æli wɑz ɛmpti, ðə hɑɹd-pæk dɝt dʒɹaɪ ən dʌsti.

Rand followed Thom's eyes. Except for half a dozen rain barrels against the inn and the next building, a tailor shop, the alley was empty, the hard-packed dirt dry and dusty.

"waɪ ɑɹ jə duɪŋ ðɪs?" mæt dɪmændəɾ əɡɛn. "jud bi seɪfɝ ɪf jə lɛft ʌs. waɪ ɑɹ jə steɪɪŋ wɪð ʌs?"

"Why are you doing this?" Mat demanded again. "You'd be safer if you left us. Why are you staying with us?"

tɑm stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm fəɹ ə lɔŋ moʊmənt. "aɪ hæɾ ə nɛfju, oʊɪn," hi sɛd wɛɹəli, ʃɹʌɡɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk. hi meɪɾ ə paɪl wɪð ɪz blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl əz i tɔkt, kɛɹfəli sɛɾɪŋ ɪz keɪst ɪnstʃɹəməns ɑn tɑp. "maɪ bɹʌðɝz oʊnli sʌn, maɪ oʊnli lɪvɪŋ kɪn. hi ɡɑɾ ɪn tʃɹʌbəl wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ aɪ wɑz tu bɪzi wɪð . . . ʌðɝ θɪŋz. aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ aɪ kəɾ əv dʌn, bʌt wən aɪ faɪnəli tʃɹaɪd, ɪt wɑz tu leɪt. oʊɪn daɪɾ ə fju jɪɹz leɪɾɝ. jə kəd seɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ kɪl hɪm." hi stʃɹeɪɾənd ʌp, nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət ðɛm. hɪz vɔɪs wɑz stɪl lɛvəl, bʌt ɹænd ɡlɪmps tɪɹz ɪn ɪz aɪz əz i tɝn ɪz hɛɾ əweɪ. "ɪf aɪ kən kip jə tu fɹi ʌv tɑɹ vəlɑn, meɪbi aɪ kən stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ oʊɪn. weɪt hɪɹ." stɪl əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ aɪz, hi hɝid tə ðə maʊθ ə ði æli, sloʊɪŋ bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ɪt. æftɝ wʌn kwɪk lʊk ɝaʊnd, hi stʃɹoʊl kæʒəwəli ɪndə ðə stʃɹiɾ ən aʊɾ ə saɪt.

Thom stared at him for a long moment. "I had a nephew, Owyn," he said wearily, shrugging out of his cloak. He made a pile with his blanketroll as he talked, carefully setting his cased instruments on top. "My brother's only son, my only living kin. He got in trouble with the Aes Sedai, but I was too busy with . . . other things. I don't know what I could have done, but when I finally tried, it was too late. Owyn died a few years later. You could say Aes Sedai killed him." He straightened up, not looking at them. His voice was still level, but Rand glimpsed tears in his eyes as he turned his head away. "If I can keep you two free of Tar Valon, maybe I can stop thinking about Owyn. Wait here." Still avoiding their eyes, he hurried to the mouth of the alley, slowing before he reached it. After one quick look around, he strolled casually into the street and out of sight.

mæt hæf ɹoʊz tə fɑloʊ, ðən sɛɾəld bæk. "hi woʊn liv ðiz," hi sɛd, tʌtʃɪŋ ðə lɛðɝ ɪnstʃɹəmən keɪsəz. "ju bɪliv ðət stɔɹi?"

Mat half rose to follow, then settled back. "He won't leave these," he said, touching the leather instrument cases. "You believe that story?"

ɹænd skwɑɾɪd peɪʃənli bɪsaɪd ðə ɹeɪn bæɹəlz. "wʌts ðə mæɾɝ wɪð ju, mæt? jə ɑɹən laɪk ðɪs. aɪ hævən hɝd jə læf ɪn deɪz."

Rand squatted patiently beside the rain barrels. "What's the matter with you, Mat? You aren't like this. I haven't heard you laugh in days."

"aɪ doʊn laɪk biɪŋ hʌntəd laɪk ə ɹæbət," mæt snæpt. hi saɪd, lɛɾɪŋ ɪz hɛd fɔl bæk əɡɛns ðə bɹɪk wɔl ə ði ɪn. ivən laɪk ðəɾ i sim tɛns. hɪz aɪz ʃɪftəd wɛɹəli. "sɑɹi. ɪts ðə ɹʌnɪŋ, ən ɔl ðiz stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, ən . . . ən dʒʌst ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ɪt meɪks mi dʒʌmpi. aɪ lʊk ət sʌmbɑɾi, ən aɪ kæn hɛlp wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf hiz gɑnə tɛl ðə feɪdz əbaʊɾ ʌs, əɹ tʃiɾ ʌs, əɹ ɹɑb ʌs, ɔɹ. . . . laɪt, ɹænd, dʌzn ɪt meɪk jə nɝvəs?"

"I don't like being hunted like a rabbit," Mat snapped. He sighed, letting his head fall back against the brick wall of the inn. Even like that he seemed tense. His eyes shifted warily. "Sorry. It's the running, and all these strangers, and . . . and just everything. It makes me jumpy. I look at somebody, and I can't help wondering if he's going to tell the Fades about us, or cheat us, or rob us, or. . . . Light, Rand, doesn't it make you nervous?"

ɹænd læft, ə kwɪk bɑɹk ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz θɹoʊt. "aɪm tu skɛɹd tə bi nɝvəs."

Rand laughed, a quick bark in the back of his throat. "I'm too scared to be nervous."

"wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd tə hɪz nɛfju?"

"What do you think the Aes Sedai did to his nephew?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ," ɹænd sɛɾ ənizəli. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli wʌn kaɪndə tʃɹʌbəl ðəɾ i nu ʌv fəɹ ə mæn tə ɡɛɾ ɪndə wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ. "nɑt laɪk ʌs, aɪ ɡɛs."

"I don't know," Rand said uneasily. There was only one kind of trouble that he knew of for a man to get into with Aes Sedai. "Not like us, I guess."

"noʊ. nɑt laɪk ʌs."

"No. Not like us."

fəɹ ə taɪm ðeɪ lin əɡɛns ðə wɔl, nɑt tɔkɪŋ. ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ haʊ lɔŋ ðeɪ weɪɾəd. ə fju mɪnəts, pɹɑbli, bʌɾ ɪt fɛlt laɪk ən aʊɝ, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ tɑm tə kʌm bæk, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ bɑɹɾɪm ən dʒɛlb tə oʊpən ðə wɪndoʊ ən dɪnaʊns əm fəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ðən ə mæn tɝn ɪn ət ðə maʊθ ə ði æli, ə tɔl mæn wɪð ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk pʊld ʌp tə haɪɾ ɪz feɪs, ə kloʊk blæk əz naɪɾ əɡɛns ðə laɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit.

For a time they leaned against the wall, not talking. Rand was not sure how long they waited. A few minutes, probably, but it felt like an hour, waiting for Thom to come back, waiting for Bartim and Gelb to open the window and denounce them for Darkfriends. Then a man turned in at the mouth of the alley, a tall man with the hood of his cloak pulled up to hide his face, a cloak black as night against the light of the street.

ɹænd skɹæmbəl tə hɪz fit, wʌn hæn ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðə hɪlt ə tæmz sɔɹd soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ ɪz nʌkəlz hɝt. hɪz maʊθ wɛn dʒɹaɪ, ən noʊ əmaʊn ə swɑloʊɪŋ hɛlpt. mæt ɹoʊz tə ə kɹaʊtʃ wɪð wʌn hæn ʌndɝ ɪz kloʊk.

Rand scrambled to his feet, one hand wrapped around the hilt of Tam's sword so hard that his knuckles hurt. His mouth went dry, and no amount of swallowing helped. Mat rose to a crouch with one hand under his cloak.

ðə mæn keɪm kloʊsɝ, ən ɹændz θɹoʊt ɡɹu taɪɾɝ wɪð ɛvɹi stɛp. əbɹʌpli ðə mæn stɑpt ən tɔs bæk ɪz kaʊl. ɹændz niz ɔlmoʊst ɡeɪv weɪ. ɪt wɑz tɑm.

The man came closer, and Rand's throat grew tighter with every step. Abruptly the man stopped and tossed back his cowl. Rand's knees almost gave way. It was Thom.

"wɛl, ɪf jə doʊn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz mi" - ðə ɡlimən ɡɹɪnd - "aɪ ɡɛs ɪts ə ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf dɪsɡaɪz fəɹ ðə ɡeɪts."

"Well, if you don't recognize me" - the gleeman grinned - "I guess it's a good enough disguise for the gates."

tɑm pʊʃt pæst əm ən bɪɡæn tʃɹænsfɝɪŋ θɪŋz fɹəm ɪz pætʃ-kʌvɝd kloʊk tə hɪz nu wʌn soʊ nɪmbli ðət ɹænd kəd nɑt meɪk aʊɾ ɛni ʌv ðɛm. ðə nu kloʊk wɑz dɑɹk bɹaʊn, ɹænd sɔ naʊ. hi dʒɹu ə dip, ɹæɡəd bɹɛθ; hɪz θɹoʊt stɪl fɛlt əz ɪf ɪt wɝ klʌtʃt ɪn ə fɪst. bɹaʊn, nɑt blæk. mæt stɪl hæɾ ɪz hæn ʌndɝ ɪz kloʊk, ən i stɛɹɾ ət tɑmz bæk əz ɪf i wɝ θɪŋkɪŋ ə juzɪŋ ðə hɪɾən dæɡɝ.

Thom pushed past them and began transferring things from his patch-covered cloak to his new one so nimbly that Rand could not make out any of them. The new cloak was dark brown, Rand saw now. He drew a deep, ragged breath; his throat still felt as if it were clutched in a fist. Brown, not black. Mat still had his hand under his cloak, and he stared at Thom's back as if he were thinking of using the hidden dagger.

tɑm ɡlænst ʌp ət ðɛm, ðən ɡeɪv əm ə ʃɑɹpɝ lʊk. "ðɪs ɪz noʊ taɪm tə ɡɛt skɪɾɪʃ." dɛfli hi bɪɡæn foʊldɪŋ ɪz oʊl kloʊk ɪndə ə bʌndəl ɝaʊn ɪz ɪnstʃɹəmən keɪsəz, ɪnsaɪɾ aʊt soʊ ðə pætʃəz wɝ hɪɾən. "wil wɔk aʊɾ ə hɪɹ wʌn əɾ ə taɪm, dʒʌs kloʊs ɪnʌf tə kip itʃ ʌðɝ ɪn saɪt. ʃʊdn bi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪspɛʃli, ðət weɪ. kæn jə slaʊtʃ?" hi æɾəd tə ɹænd. "ðæt haɪɾ ə jʊɹz ɪz əz bæɾ əz ə bænɝ." hi slʌŋ ðə bʌndəl əkɹɔs ɪz bæk ən stʊd, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪz hʊd bæk ʌp. hi lʊk nʌθɪŋ laɪk ə waɪt-hɛɹd ɡlimən. hi wɑz dʒʌst ənʌðɝ tʃɹævəlɝ, ə mæn tu pʊɹ tə əfɔɹɾ ə hɔɹs, mʌtʃ lɛs ə kæɹɪdʒ. "lɛts ɡoʊ. wiv weɪstəd tu mʌtʃ taɪm ɔlɹɛɾi."

Thom glanced up at them, then gave them a sharper look. "This is no time to get skittish." Deftly he began folding his old cloak into a bundle around his instrument cases, inside out so the patches were hidden. "We'll walk out of here one at a time, just close enough to keep each other in sight. Shouldn't be remembered especially, that way. Can't you slouch?" he added to Rand. "That height of yours is as bad as a banner." He slung the bundle across his back and stood, drawing his hood back up. He looked nothing like a white-haired gleeman. He was just another traveler, a man too poor to afford a horse, much less a carriage. "Let's go. We've wasted too much time already."

ɹænd əɡɹid fɝvənli, bʌɾ ivən soʊ hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ stɛpɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði æli ɪndə ðə skwɛɹ. nʌn ə ðə spɑɹs skæɾɝɪŋ ə pipəl ɡeɪv əm ə sɛkən lʊk - moʊs dɪd nɑt lʊk əɾ əm əɾ ɔl - bʌɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz nɑɾɪd, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə kɹaɪ ʌv dɑɹkfɹɛn ðət kəd tɝn ɔɹɾənɛɹi pipəl ɪndə ə mɑb bɛn ɑn mɝɾɝ. hi ɹæn ɪz aɪz əkɹɔs ði oʊpən ɛɹiə, oʊvɝ pipəl muvɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɑn ðɛɹ deɪli bɪznəs, ən wən i bɹɔɾ əm bæk ə mɹdʒɹɑl wɑz hæfweɪ əkɹɔs ðə skwɛɹ.

Rand agreed fervently, but even so he hesitated before stepping out of the alley into the square. None of the sparse scattering of people gave them a second look - most did not look at them at all - but his shoulders knotted, waiting for the cry of Darkfriend that could turn ordinary people into a mob bent on murder. He ran his eyes across the open area, over people moving about on their daily business, and when he brought them back a Myrddraal was halfway across the square.

wɛɹ ðə feɪd hæd kʌm fɹʌm, hi kəd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə ɡɛs, bʌɾ ɪt stʃɹoʊd təwɔɹd ðə θɹi ʌv əm wɪð ə sloʊ dɛdlinəs, ə pɹɛɾətɝ wɪð ðə pɹeɪ ʌndɝ ɪts ɡeɪz. pipəl ʃaɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə blæk-kloʊkt ʃeɪp, əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪt. ðə skwɛɹ bɪɡæn tə ɛmpti aʊɾ əz pipəl dɪsaɪɾɪd ðeɪ wɝ niɾəd ɛlswɛɹ.

Where the Fade had come from, he could not begin to guess, but it strode toward the three of them with a slow deadliness, a predator with the prey under its gaze. People shied away from the black-cloaked shape, avoided looking at it. The square began to empty out as people decided they were needed elsewhere.

ðə blæk kaʊl fɹoʊz ɹænd wɛɹ i stʊd. hi tʃɹaɪd tə sʌmən ʌp ðə vɔɪd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz laɪk fʌmbəlɪŋ æftɝ smoʊk. ðə feɪdz hɪɾən ɡeɪz naɪfɛd tə hɪz boʊnz ən tɝn ɪz mɛɹoʊ tə aɪsɪkəlz.

The black cowl froze Rand where he stood. He tried to summon up the void, but it was like fumbling after smoke. The Fade's hidden gaze knifed to his bones and turned his marrow to icicles.

"doʊn lʊk əɾ ɪts feɪs," tɑm mʌɾɝd. hɪz vɔɪs ʃʊk ən kɹækt, ən ɪt saʊndəɾ əz ɪf i wɝ fɔɹsɪŋ ðə wɝdz aʊt. "ðə laɪt bɝn ju, doʊn lʊk əɾ ɪts feɪs!"

"Don't look at its face," Thom muttered. His voice shook and cracked, and it sounded as if he were forcing the words out. "The Light burn you, don't look at its face!"

ɹænd tɔɹ ɪz aɪz əweɪ - hi ɔlmoʊst ɡɹoʊnd; ɪt fɛlt laɪk tɛɹɪŋ ə litʃ ɔf ə hɪz feɪs - bʌɾ ivən stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə stoʊnz ə ðə skwɛɹ i kəd stɪl si ðə mɹdʒɹɑl kʌmɪŋ, ə kæt pleɪɪŋ wɪð maɪs, əmjuzd ət ðɛɹ fibəl ɛfɝts tə ɪskeɪp, əntɪl faɪnəli ðə dʒɔz snæpt ʃʌt. ðə feɪd hæd hæv ðə dɪstəns. "ɑɹ wi dʒʌs gɑnə stæn hɪɹ?" hi mʌmbəld. "wi hæv tə ɹʌn . . . ɡɛɾ əweɪ." bʌɾ i kəd nɑt meɪk ɪz fit muv.

Rand tore his eyes away - he almost groaned; it felt like tearing a leech off of his face - but even staring at the stones of the square he could still see the Myrddraal coming, a cat playing with mice, amused at their feeble efforts to escape, until finally the jaws snapped shut. The Fade had halved the distance. "Are we just going to stand here?" he mumbled. "We have to run . . . get away." But he could not make his feet move.

mæt hæd ðə ɹubi-hɪltɪd dæɡɝ aʊɾ ət læst, ɪn ə tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ hænd. hɪz lɪps wɝ dʒɹɔn bæk fɹəm ɪz tiθ, ə snɑɹl ən ə ɹɪktəs ə fɪɹ.

Mat had the ruby-hilted dagger out at last, in a trembling hand. His lips were drawn back from his teeth, a snarl and a rictus of fear.

"θɪŋk. . . ." tɑm stɑp tə swɑloʊ, ən wɛn ɑn hɔɹsli. "θɪŋk jə kən aʊtʃɹʌn ɪt, də ju, bɔɪ?" hi bɪɡæn tə mʌɾɝ tə hɪmsɛlf; ði oʊnli wɝd ɹænd kəd meɪk aʊt wɑz "oʊɪn." əbɹʌpli tɑm ɡɹaʊld, "aɪ nɛvɝ ʃʊɾə ɡɑɾən mɪkst ʌp wɪð jə bɔɪz. ʃəd nɛvɝ hæv." hi ʃɹʌɡd ðə bʌndəld ɡlimənz kloʊk ɔf ə hɪz bæk ən θɹʌst ɪɾ ɪndə ɹændz ɑɹmz. "teɪk kɛɹ ə ðæt. wən aɪ seɪ ɹʌn, jə ɹʌn ən doʊn stɑp əntɪl jə ɡɛt tə keɪɛmlɪn. ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ. ən ɪn. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðæt, ɪn keɪs. . . . dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪt."

"Think. . . ." Thom stopped to swallow, and went on hoarsely. "Think you can outrun it, do you, boy?" He began to mutter to himself; the only word Rand could make out was "Owyn." Abruptly Thom growled, "I never should have gotten mixed up with you boys. Should never have." He shrugged the bundled gleeman's cloak off of his back and thrust it into Rand's arms. "Take care of that. When I say run, you run and don't stop until you get to Caemlyn. The Queen's Blessing. An inn. Remember that, in case. . . . Just remember it."

"aɪ doʊn ʌndɝstænd," ɹænd sɛd. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl wɑz nɑt twɛnti peɪsɪz əweɪ, naʊ. hɪz fit fɛlt laɪk lɛd weɪts.

"I don't understand," Rand said. The Myrddraal was not twenty paces away, now. His feet felt like lead weights.

"dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪt!" tɑm snɑɹəld. "ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ. naʊ. ɹʌn!"

"Just remember it!" Thom snarled. "The Queen's Blessing. Now. RUN!"

hi ɡeɪv əm ə pʊʃ, wʌn hæn ɑn ðə ʃoʊldɝ ʌv itʃ ə ðɛm, tə ɡɛɾ əm stɑɹɾəd, ən ɹænd stʌmbəld əweɪ ɪn ə lɝtʃɪŋ ɹʌn wɪð mæt əɾ ɪz saɪd.

He gave them a push, one hand on the shoulder of each of them, to get them started, and Rand stumbled away in a lurching run with Mat at his side.

"ɹʌn!" tɑm spɹæŋ ɪndə moʊʃən, tu, wɪð ə lɔŋ, wɝdləs ɹɔɹ. nɑɾ æftɝ ðɛm, bʌt təwɔɹd ðə mɹdʒɹɑl. hɪz hænz flɝɪʃt əz ɪf i wɝ pɝfɔɹmɪŋ əɾ ɪz bɛst, ən dæɡɝz əpɪɹd. ɹænd stɑpt, bʌt mæt pʊld ɪm əlɔŋ.

"RUN!" Thom sprang into motion, too, with a long, wordless roar. Not after them, but toward the Myrddraal. His hands flourished as if he were performing at his best, and daggers appeared. Rand stopped, but Mat pulled him along.

ðə feɪd wɑz dʒʌst əz stɑɹɾəld. ɪts lizɝli peɪs fɔltɝɾ ɪn mɪd-stʃɹaɪd. ɪts hæn swɛp təwɔɹd ðə hɪlt ə ðə blæk sɔɹd hæŋɪŋ əɾ ɪts weɪst, bʌt ðə ɡlimənz lɔŋ lɛɡz kʌvɝd ðə dɪstəns kwɪkli. tɑm kɹæʃt ɪndə ðə mɹdʒɹɑl bɪfɔɹ ðə blæk bleɪd wɑz hæf dʒɹɔn, ən boʊθ wɛn daʊn ɪn ə θɹæʃɪŋ hip. ðə fju pipəl stɪl ɪn ðə skwɛɹ flɛd.

The Fade was just as startled. Its leisurely pace faltered in mid-stride. Its hand swept toward the hilt of the black sword hanging at its waist, but the gleeman's long legs covered the distance quickly. Thom crashed into the Myrddraal before the black blade was half drawn, and both went down in a thrashing heap. The few people still in the square fled.

"ɹʌn!" ði ɛɹ ɪn ðə skwɛɹ flæʃt ən aɪ-sɪɹɪŋ blu, ən tɑm bɪɡæn tə skɹim, bʌɾ ivən ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə skɹim i mænədʒd ə wɝd. "ɹʌn!"

"RUN!" The air in the square flashed an eye-searing blue, and Thom began to scream, but even in the middle of the scream he managed a word. "RUN!"

ɹænd oʊbeɪd. ðə ɡlimənz skɹimz pɝsud hɪm.

Rand obeyed. The gleeman's screams pursued him.

klʌtʃɪŋ tɑmz bʌndəl tə hɪz tʃɛst, hi ɹæn əz hɑɹɾ əz i kʊd. pænɪk spɹɛd fɹəm ðə skwɛɹ aʊt θɹu ðə taʊn əz ɹænd ən mæt flɛɾ ɑn ðə kɹɛst ʌv ə weɪv ə fɪɹ. ʃɑpkipɝz əbændən ðɛɹ ɡʊdz əz ðə bɔɪz pæst. ʃʌɾɝz bæŋ daʊn oʊvɝ stɔɹfɹɑns, ən fɹaɪɾənd feɪsəz əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz ə haʊsəz, ðən vænɪʃt. pipəl u hæd nɑt bɪn kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si ɹæn θɹu ðə stʃɹits waɪldli, peɪɪŋ noʊ hid. ðeɪ bʌmpt ɪndə wʌn ənʌðɝ, ən ðoʊz u wɝ nɑk daʊn skɹæmbəl tə ðɛɹ fiɾ əɹ wɝ tʃɹæmpəld. waɪtbɹɪdʒ ɹɔɪld laɪk ə kɪkt æntɪl.

Clutching Thom's bundle to his chest, he ran as hard as he could. Panic spread from the square out through the town as Rand and Mat fled on the crest of a wave of fear. Shopkeepers abandoned their goods as the boys passed. Shutters banged down over storefronts, and frightened faces appeared in the windows of houses, then vanished. People who had not been close enough to see ran through the streets wildly, paying no heed. They bumped into one another, and those who were knocked down scrambled to their feet or were trampled. Whitebridge roiled like a kicked anthill.

əz i ən mæt paʊndɪd təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪts, ɹænd əbɹʌpli ɹɪmɛmbɝd wʌt tɑm hæd sɛɾ əbaʊɾ ɪz haɪt. wɪθaʊt sloʊɪŋ daʊn, hi kɹaʊtʃt əz bɛst i kəd wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ əz ɪf i wɑz kɹaʊtʃɪŋ. bʌt ðə ɡeɪts ðɛmsɛlvz, θɪk wʊd baʊnd wɪð blæk aɪɝn stʃɹæps, stʊɾ oʊpən. ðə tu ɡəttɛndɝz, ɪn stil kæps ən meɪl tunɪks wɔɹn oʊvɝ tʃip-lʊkɪŋ ɹɛd koʊts wɪð waɪt kɑlɝz, fɪŋɡɝd ðɛɹ hælbɝdz ən stɛɹɾ ənizəli ɪndə ðə taʊn. wʌn ə ðɛm ɡlænst ət ɹænd ən mæt, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ði oʊnli wʌnz ɹʌnɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɡeɪts. ə stɛɾi stʃɹim bɔɪl θɹu, pæntɪŋ mɛn klʌtʃɪŋ waɪvz, wipɪŋ wɪmən kæɹiɪŋ beɪbz ən dʒɹæɡɪŋ kɹaɪɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən, peɪl-feɪs kɹæfsmən stɪl ɪn ðɛɹ eɪpɹənz, stɪl hidləsli ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðɛɹ tulz.

As he and Mat pounded toward the gates, Rand abruptly remembered what Thom had said about his height. Without slowing down, he crouched as best he could without looking as if he was crouching. But the gates themselves, thick wood bound with black iron straps, stood open. The two gatetenders, in steel caps and mail tunics worn over cheap-looking red coats with white collars, fingered their halberds and stared uneasily into the town. One of them glanced at Rand and Mat, but they were not the only ones running out of the gates. A steady stream boiled through, panting men clutching wives, weeping women carrying babes and dragging crying children, pale-faced craftsmen still in their aprons, still heedlessly gripping their tools.

ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ wʌn u kəd tɛl wɪtʃ weɪ ðeɪ hæd ɡɔn, ɹænd θɔɾ əz i ɹæn, deɪzd. tɑm. oʊ, laɪt seɪv mi, tɑm.

There would be no one who could tell which way they had gone, Rand thought as he ran, dazed. Thom. Oh, Light save me, Thom.

mæt stæɡɝd bɪsaɪd hɪm, kɑɾ ɪz bæləns, ən ðeɪ ɹæn əntɪl ðə læst ə ðə fliɪŋ pipəl hæd fɔlən əweɪ, ɹæn əntɪl ðə taʊn ən ðə waɪt bɹɪdʒ wɝ fɑɹ aʊɾ ə saɪt bɪhaɪn ðɛm.

Mat staggered beside him, caught his balance, and they ran until the last of the fleeing people had fallen away, ran until the town and the White Bridge were far out of sight behind them.

faɪnəli ɹænd fɛl tə hɪz niz ɪn ðə dʌst, pʊlɪŋ ɛɹ ɹæədli ɪndə hɪz ɹɔ θɹoʊt wɪð ɡɹeɪt ɡʌlps. ðə ɹoʊd bɪhaɪn stʃɹɛtʃt ɛmpti əntɪl ɪt wɑz lɔs tə saɪɾ əmʌŋ bɛɹ tʃɹiz. mæt plʌkt ət hɪm.

Finally Rand fell to his knees in the dust, pulling air raggedly into his raw throat with great gulps. The road behind stretched empty until it was lost to sight among bare trees. Mat plucked at him.

"kʌm ɑn. kʌm ɑn." mæt pæntɪd ðə wɝdz. swɛɾ ən dʌst stʃɹikt ɪz feɪs, ən i lʊkt ɹɛɾi tə kəlæps. "wi hæv tə kip ɡoʊɪŋ."

"Come on. Come on." Mat panted the words. Sweat and dust streaked his face, and he looked ready to collapse. "We have to keep going."

"tɑm," ɹænd sɛd. hi taɪɾənd ɪz ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ðə bʌndəl ə tɑmz kloʊk; ði ɪnstʃɹəmən keɪsəz wɝ hɑɹd lʌmps ɪnsaɪd. "tɑm."

"Thom," Rand said. He tightened his arms around the bundle of Thom's cloak; the instrument cases were hard lumps inside. "Thom."

"hiz dɛd. jə sɔ. jə hɝd. laɪt, ɹænd, hiz dɛd!"

"He's dead. You saw. You heard. Light, Rand, he's dead!"

"ju θɪŋk ɛɡwin ən mɔɪɹeɪn ən ðə ɹɛst ɑɹ dɛd, tu. ɪf ðəɹ dɛd, waɪ ɑɹ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl stɪl hʌntɪŋ ðɛm? ænsɝ mi ðæt?"

"You think Egwene and Moiraine and the rest are dead, too. If they're dead, why are the Myrddraal still hunting them? Answer me that?"

mæt dʒɹɑp tə hɪz niz ɪn ðə dʌs bɪsaɪd hɪm. "ɔl ɹaɪt. meɪbi ðeɪ ɑɹ əlaɪv. bʌt tɑm - jə sɔ! blʌɾ ən æʃəz, ɹænd, ðə seɪm θɪŋ kən hæpən tə ʌs."

Mat dropped to his knees in the dust beside him. "All right. Maybe they are alive. But Thom - You saw! Blood and ashes, Rand, the same thing can happen to us."

ɹænd nɑɾəd sloʊli. ðə ɹoʊd bɪhaɪn əm wɑz stɪl ɛmpti. hi hæd bɪn hæfweɪ ɪkspɛktɪŋ - hoʊpɪŋ, ət list - tə si tɑm əpɪɹ, stʃɹaɪɾɪŋ əlɔŋ, bloʊɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz mʌstæʃɪz tə tɛl əm haʊ mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl ðeɪ wɝ. ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. hi stʃɹʌɡəl tə hɪz fiɾ ən slʌŋ tɑmz bʌndəl ɑn ɪz bæk əlɔŋsaɪɾ ɪz blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl. mæt stɛɹɾ ʌp ət hɪm, nɛɹoʊ-aɪɾ ən wɛɹi.

Rand nodded slowly. The road behind them was still empty. He had been halfway expecting - hoping, at least - to see Thom appear, striding along, blowing out his mustaches to tell them how much trouble they were. The Queen's Blessing in Caemlyn. He struggled to his feet and slung Thom's bundle on his back alongside his blanketroll. Mat stared up at him, narrow-eyed and wary.

"lɛts ɡoʊ," ɹænd sɛd, ən stɑɹɾəd daʊn ðə ɹoʊd təwɔɹd keɪɛmlɪn. hi hɝd mæt mʌɾɝɪŋ, ən æftɝ ə moʊmən i kɑɾ ʌp tə ɹænd.

"Let's go," Rand said, and started down the road toward Caemlyn. He heard Mat muttering, and after a moment he caught up to Rand.

ðeɪ tʃɹʌdʒd əlɔŋ ðə dʌsti ɹoʊd, hɛdz daʊn ən nɑt tɔkɪŋ. ðə wɪn spɔn dʌstdɛv ɪlz ðət wɝld əkɹɔs ðɛɹ pæθ. səmtaɪmz ɹænd lʊk bæk, bʌt ðə ɹoʊd bɪhaɪnd wɑz ɔlweɪz ɛmpti.

They trudged along the dusty road, heads down and not talking. The wind spawned dustdev ils that whirled across their path. Sometimes Rand looked back, but the road behind was always empty.


tʃæptɝ twɛntisɛvən


CHAPTER 27

ʃɛltɝ fɹəm ðə stɔɹm


Shelter From the Storm

pɛɹɪn fɹɛɾɪd oʊvɝ ðə deɪz spɛnt wɪð ðə tuætɑn, tʃɹævlɪŋ saʊθ ən ist ɪn ə lizɝli fæʃən. ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl sɔ noʊ nid tə hɝi; ðeɪ nɛvɝ dɪd. ðə kʌlɝfəl wæɡənz dɪd nɑt ɹoʊl aʊɾ ʌv ə mɔɹnɪŋ əntɪl ðə sʌn wɑz wɛl əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən, ən ðeɪ stɑpt əz ɝli əz mɪɾ æftɝnun ɪf ðeɪ keɪm əkɹɔs ə kəndʒinjəl spɑt. ðə dɑɡz tʃɹɑɾəd izəli əlɔŋsaɪd ðə wæɡənz, ən ɔfən ðə tʃɪlʒɹən dɪd, tu. ðeɪ hæd noʊ dɪfəkəlti ɪn kipɪŋ ʌp. ɛni sədʒɛstʃən ðət ðeɪ maɪt ɡoʊ fɝðɝ, əɹ mɔɹ kwɪkli, wɑz mɛt wɪð læftɝ, əɹ pɝhæps, "ɑ, bʌt wəd jə meɪk ðə pʊɹ hɔɹsəz wɝk soʊ hɑɹd?"

Perrin fretted over the days spent with the Tuatha'an, traveling south and east in a leisurely fashion. The Traveling People saw no need to hurry; they never did. The colorful wagons did not roll out of a morning until the sun was well above the horizon, and they stopped as early as mid afternoon if they came across a congenial spot. The dogs trotted easily alongside the wagons, and often the children did, too. They had no difficulty in keeping up. Any suggestion that they might go further, or more quickly, was met with laughter, or perhaps, "Ah, but would you make the poor horses work so hard?"

hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ ɛlaɪəs dɪd nɑt ʃɛɹ ɪz filɪŋz. ɛlaɪəs wəd nɑt ɹaɪɾ ɑn ðə wæɡənz - hi pɹəfɝd tə wɔk, səmtaɪmz ləpɪŋ əlɔŋ ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kɑləm - bʌɾ i nɛvɝ sədʒɛstəd livɪŋ, əɹ pɹɛsɪŋ ɑn əhɛd.

He was surprised that Elyas did not share his feelings. Elyas would not ride on the wagons - he preferred to walk, sometimes loping along at the head of the column - but he never suggested leaving, or pressing on ahead.

ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ bɪɹɾəd mæn ɪn ɪz stʃɹeɪnʒ skɪn kloʊðz wɑz soʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ðə dʒɛntəl tuætɑn ðəɾ i stʊɾ aʊt wɛɹɛvɝ i wɛn əmʌŋ ðə wæɡənz. ivən fɹəm əkɹɔs ðə kæmp ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ɛlaɪəs fəɹ wʌn ə ðə pipəl, ən nɑt dʒʌs kəz ə kloʊðz. ɛlaɪəs muvd wɪð ðə leɪzi ɡɹeɪs ʌv ə wʊlf, oʊnli ɛmfəsaɪz baɪ hɪz skɪnz ən ɪz fɝ hæt, ɹeɪɾieɪtɪŋ deɪnʒɝ əz nætʃɹəli əz ə faɪɝ ɹeɪɾieɪtəd hit, ən ðə kɑntʃɹæst wɪð ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl wɑz ʃɑɹp. jʌŋ ən oʊld, ðə pipəl wɝ dʒɔɪfəl ɑn ðɛɹ fit. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ deɪnʒɝ ɪn ðɛɹ ɡɹeɪs, oʊnli dɪlaɪt. ðɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹən dɑɹɾɪd əbaʊt fɪld wɪð ðə pjʊɹ zɛst ə muvɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ əmʌŋ ðə tuætɑn, ɡɹeɪbɛɪɹdz ən ɡɹændmʌðɝz, tu, stɪl stɛp laɪtli, ðɛɹ wɔk ə steɪtli dæns noʊ lɛs ɪɡzubɝən fəɹ ɪts dɪɡnəɾi. ɔl ðə pipəl simd ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə dænsɪŋ, ivən wən stændɪŋ stɪl, ivən dʊɹɪŋ ðə ɹɛɹ taɪmz wən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mjuzɪk ɪn ðə kæmp. fɪɾəlz ən fluts, dʌlsɪmɝz ən zɪðɝz ən dʒɹʌmz spʌn hɑɹməni ən kaʊntɝpɔɪn ɝaʊn ðə wæɡənz əɾ ɔlmoʊst ɛni aʊɝ, ɪn kæmp əɹ ɑn ðə muv. dʒɔɪəs sɔŋz, mɛɹi sɔŋz, læfɪŋ sɔŋz, sæd sɔŋz; ɪf sʌmwʌn wɑz əweɪk ɪn ðə kæmp ðəɹ wɑz juʒəwəli mjuzɪk.

The strange bearded man in his strange skin clothes was so different from the gentle Tuatha'an that he stood out wherever he went among the wagons. Even from across the camp there was no mistaking Elyas for one of the People, and not just because of clothes. Elyas moved with the lazy grace of a wolf, only emphasized by his skins and his fur hat, radiating danger as naturally as a fire radiated heat, and the contrast with the Traveling People was sharp. Young and old, the People were joyful on their feet. There was no danger in their grace, only delight. Their children darted about filled with the pure zest of moving, of course, but among the Tuatha'an, graybeards and grandmothers, too, still stepped lightly, their walk a stately dance no less exuberant for its dignity. All the People seemed on the point of dancing, even when standing still, even during the rare times when there was no music in the camp. Fiddles and flutes, dulcimers and zithers and drums spun harmony and counterpoint around the wagons at almost any hour, in camp or on the move. Joyous songs, merry songs, laughing songs, sad songs; if someone was awake in the camp there was usually music.

ɛlaɪəs mɛt fɹɛnli nɑdz ən smaɪlz əɾ ɛvɹi wæɡən i pæst, ən ə tʃɪɹfəl wɝɾ əɾ ɛni faɪɝ wɛɹ i pɔzd. ðɪs mʌs bi ðə feɪs ðə pipəl ɔlweɪz ʃoʊd tə aʊtsaɪɾɝz - oʊpən, smaɪlɪŋ feɪsəz. bʌt pɛɹɪn hæd lɝn ðət hɪɾən bɪniθ ðə sɝfəs wɑz ðə wɛɹinɪs ʌv ə hæf-teɪm dɪɹ. sʌmθɪŋ dip leɪ bɪhaɪn ðə smaɪlz dɝɛktəɾ ət ði ɛmənz fildɝz, sʌmθɪŋ ðət wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ seɪf, sʌmθɪŋ ðət feɪɾəd oʊnli slaɪtli oʊvɝ ðə deɪz. wɪð ɛlaɪəs ðə wɛɹinɪs wɑz stʃɹɔŋ, laɪk dip sʌmɝ hit ʃɪmɝɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ən ɪt dɪd nɑt feɪd. wən i wɑz nɑt lʊkɪŋ ðeɪ wɑtʃt ɪm oʊpənli əz ɪf ənʃʊɹ wʌɾ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə du. wən i wɔkt əkɹɔs ðə kæmp, fit ɹɛɾi fəɹ dænsɪŋ simd ɹɛɾi fəɹ flaɪt, əz wɛl.

Elyas met friendly nods and smiles at every wagon he passed, and a cheerful word at any fire where he paused. This must be the face the People always showed to outsiders - open, smiling faces. But Perrin had learned that hidden beneath the surface was the wariness of a half-tame deer. Something deep lay behind the smiles directed at the Emond's Fielders, something that wondered if they were safe, something that faded only slightly over the days. With Elyas the wariness was strong, like deep summer heat shimmering in the air, and it did not fade. When he was not looking they watched him openly as if unsure what he was going to do. When he walked across the camp, feet ready for dancing seemed ready for flight, as well.

ɛlaɪəs wɑz sɝɾənli noʊ mɔɹ kʌmftəɹbəl wɪð ðɛɹ weɪ ʌv ðə lif ðən ðeɪ wɝ wɪð hɪm. hɪz maʊθ wɔɹ ə pɝmənən twɪst wən i wɑz ɝaʊn ðə tuætɑn. ɪt wɑz nɑt kwaɪt kɑndəsɛnʃən ən sɝɾənli nɑt kəntɛmpt, bʌt lʊkt əz ðoʊ hi wəd ɹæðɝ bi ɛlswɛɹ ðən wɛɹ i wɑz, ɔlmoʊst ɛniwɛɹ ɛls. jɛt wɛnɛvɝ pɛɹɪn bɹɔɾ ʌp livɪŋ, ɛlaɪəs meɪd suðɪŋ nɔɪzɪz əbaʊt ɹɛstɪŋ, dʒʌs fəɹ ə fju deɪz.

Elyas was certainly no more comfortable with their Way of the Leaf than they were with him. His mouth wore a permanent twist when he was around the Tuatha'an. It was not quite condescension and certainly not contempt, but looked as though he would rather be elsewhere than where he was, almost anywhere else. Yet whenever Perrin brought up leaving, Elyas made soothing noises about resting, just for a few days.

"ju hæd hɑɹd deɪz bɪfɔɹ jə mɛt mi," ɛlaɪəs sɛd, ðə θɝɾ əɹ fɔɹθ taɪm i æskt, "æn jəl əv hɑɹɾɝ stɪl əhɛd, wɪð tʃɹɑləks ən hæfmən æftɝ ju, ən ɛɛs sədaɪ fəɹ fɹɛnz." hi ɡɹɪn ɝaʊn ə maʊθfʊl ʌv iləz dʒɹaɪd-æpəl paɪ. pɛɹɪn stɪl faʊn ɪz jɛloʊ-aɪd ɡeɪz dɪskənsɝɾɪŋ, ivən wən i wɑz smaɪlɪŋ. pɝhæps ivən mɔɹ wən i wɑz smaɪlɪŋ; smaɪlz sɛldəm tʌtʃt ðoʊz hʌntɝz aɪz. ɛlaɪəs laʊnʒd bɪsaɪd ɹənz faɪɝ, əz juʒəwəl ɹəfjuzɪŋ tə sɪɾ ɑn ðə lɔɡz dʒɹɔn ʌp fəɹ ðə pɝpəs. "doʊn bi ɪn sətʃ ə blʌɾi hɝi tə pʊt jɝsɛlf ɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ hænz."

"You had hard days before you met me," Elyas said, the third or fourth time he asked, "and you'll have harder still ahead, with Trollocs and Halfmen after you, and Aes Sedai for friends." He grinned around a mouthful of Ila's dried-apple pie. Perrin still found his yellow-eyed gaze disconcerting, even when he was smiling. Perhaps even more when he was smiling; smiles seldom touched those hunter's eyes. Elyas lounged beside Raen's fire, as usual refusing to sit on the logs drawn up for the purpose. "Don't be in such a bloody hurry to put yourself in Aes Sedai hands."

"wʌɾ ɪf ðə feɪdz faɪn ʌs? wʌts tə kip əm fɹəm ɪɾ ɪf wi dʒʌst sɪt hɪɹ, weɪɾɪŋ? θɹi wʊlvz kæn hoʊld əm ɔf, ən ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl woʊn bi ɛni hɛlp. ðeɪ woʊn ivən dɪfɛn ðɛmsɛlvz. ðə tʃɹɑləks wɪl bʊtʃɝ ðɛm, ən ɪɾəl bi əɹ fɔlt. ɛniweɪ, wɪv tə liv əm sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ. ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl bi sunɝ."

"What if the Fades find us? What's to keep them from it if we just sit here, waiting? Three wolves can't hold them off, and the Traveling People won't be any help. They won't even defend themselves. The Trollocs will butcher them, and it will be our fault. Anyway, we have to leave them sooner or later. It might as well be sooner."

"sʌmθɪŋ tɛlz mi tə weɪt. dʒʌst ə fju deɪz."

"Something tells me to wait. Just a few days."

"sʌmθɪŋ!"

"Something!"

"ɹɪlæks, læd. teɪk laɪf əz ɪt kʌmz. ɹʌn wən juv tə, faɪt wən jə mʌst, ɹɛst wən jə kæn."

"Relax, lad. Take life as it comes. Run when you have to, fight when you must, rest when you can."

"wʌɾ ɑɹ jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt, sʌmθɪŋ?"

"What are you talking about, something?"

"hæv səm ə ðɪs paɪ. ilə dʌzn laɪk mi, bʌt ʃi ʃʊɹli fidz mi wɛl wən aɪ vɪzət. ɔlweɪz ɡʊd fuɾ ɪn ðə pipəlz kæmps."

"Have some of this pie. Ila doesn't like me, but she surely feeds me well when I visit. Always good food in the People's camps."

"wʌt 'sʌmθɪŋ'?" pɛɹɪn dɪmændəd. "ɪf jə noʊ sʌmθɪŋ jə ɑɹən tɛlɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs. . . ."

"What 'something'?" Perrin demanded. "If you know something you aren't telling the rest of us. . . ."

ɛlaɪəs fɹaʊn ət ðə pis ə paɪ ɪn ɪz hænd, ðən sɛɾ ɪt daʊn ən dʌstɪɾ ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ. "sʌmθɪŋ," hi sɛd faɪnəli, wɪð ə ʃɹʌɡ ʌv ɪz ʃoʊldɝz əz ɪf i dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɪt kəmplitli hɪmsɛlf. "sʌmθɪŋ tɛlz mi ɪts ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə weɪt. ə fju mɔɹ deɪz. aɪ doʊnt ɡɛt filɪŋz laɪk ðɪs ɔfən, bʌt wən aɪ du, aɪv lɝn tə tʃɹʌs ðɛm. ðeɪv seɪv maɪ laɪf ɪn ðə pæst. ðɪs taɪm ɪts dɪfɹənt, sʌmhaʊ, bʌɾ ɪts ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ðæts klɪɹ. jə wɑnə ɹʌn ɑn, ðən ɹʌn ɑn. nɑt mi."

Elyas frowned at the piece of pie in his hand, then set it down and dusted his hands together. "Something," he said finally, with a shrug of his shoulders as if he did not understand it completely himself. "Something tells me it's important to wait. A few more days. I don't get feelings like this often, but when I do, I've learned to trust them. They've saved my life in the past. This time it's different, somehow, but it's important. That's clear. You want to run on, then run on. Not me."

ðət wɑz ɔl i wəd seɪ, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mɛni taɪmz pɛɹɪn æskt. hi leɪ əbaʊt, tɔkɪŋ wɪð ɹən, iɾɪŋ, næpɪŋ wɪð ɪz hæɾ oʊvɝ ɪz aɪz, ən ɹəfjuz tə dɪskʌs livɪŋ. sʌmθɪŋ toʊld ɪm tə weɪt. sʌmθɪŋ toʊld ɪm ɪt wɑz ɪmpɔɹɾənt. hi wəd noʊ wən ɪt wɑz taɪm tə ɡoʊ. hæv səm paɪ, læd. doʊn læðɝ jɝsɛlf. tʃɹaɪ səm ə ðɪs stu. ɹɪlæks.

That was all he would say, no matter how many times Perrin asked. He lay about, talking with Raen, eating, napping with his hat over his eyes, and refused to discuss leaving. Something told him to wait. Something told him it was important. He would know when it was time to go. Have some pie, lad. Don't lather yourself. Try some of this stew. Relax.

pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt meɪk hɪmsɛlf ɹɪlæks. ət naɪɾ i wɑndɝɾ əmʌŋ ðə ɹeɪnboʊ wæɡənz wɝiɪŋ, əz mʌtʃ kəz noʊ wʌn ɛls sim tə si ɛniθɪŋ tə wɝi əbaʊɾ əz fəɹ ɛni ʌðɝ ɹizən. ðə tuætɑn sæŋ ən dænst, kʊkt ən eɪɾ ɝaʊn ðɛɹ kæmpfaɪɝz - fɹuts ən nʌts, bɛɹiz ən vɛdʒtəbəlz; ðeɪ eɪt noʊ mit - ən wɛn əbaʊɾ ə mɪɹiəd dəmɛstɪk tʃɔɹz əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑɾ ə kɛɹ ɪn ðə wɝld. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ɹæn ən pleɪɾ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, haɪd-ænd-sik əmʌŋ ðə wæɡənz, klaɪmɪŋ ɪn ðə tʃɹiz ɝaʊn ðə kæmp, læfɪŋ ən ɹoʊlɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪð ðə dɑɡz. nɑɾ ə kɛɹ ɪn ðə wɝld, fəɹ ɛniwʌn.

Perrin could not make himself relax. At night he wandered among the rainbow wagons worrying, as much because no one else seemed to see anything to worry about as for any other reason. The Tuatha'an sang and danced, cooked and ate around their campfires - fruits and nuts, berries and vegetables; they ate no meat - and went about a myriad domestic chores as if they had not a care in the world. The children ran and played everywhere, hide-and-seek among the wagons, climbing in the trees around the camp, laughing and rolling on the ground with the dogs. Not a care in the world, for anyone.

wɑtʃɪŋ ðɛm, hi ɪtʃt tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ. ɡoʊ, bɪfɔɹ wi bɹɪŋ ðə hʌntɝz daʊn ɑn ðɛm. ðeɪ tʊk əs ɪn, ən wi ɹipeɪ ðɛɹ kaɪndnəs baɪ ɛndeɪnʒɝɪŋ ðɛm. ət lis ðeɪv ɹizən tə bi laɪthɑɹɾɪd. nʌθɪŋ ɪz hʌntɪŋ ðɛm. bʌt ðə ɹɛst ʌv ʌs. . . .

Watching them, he itched to get away. Go, before we bring the hunters down on them. They took us in, and we repay their kindness by endangering them. At least they have reason to be lighthearted. Nothing is hunting them. But the rest of us. . . .

ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə ɡɛɾ ə wɝd wɪð ɛɡwin. iðɝ ʃi wɑz tɔkɪŋ wɪð ilə, ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ ɪn ə weɪ ðət sɛd noʊ mɛn wɝ wɛlkəm, əɹ ʃi wɑz dænsɪŋ wɪð ɛɹæm, swɪŋɪŋ ɹaʊn ən ɹaʊn tə ðə fluts ən fɪɾəlz ən dʒɹʌmz, tə tunz ðə tuætɑn hæd ɡæðɝd fɹəm ɔl oʊvɝ ðə wɝld, əɹ tə ðə ʃɑɹp, tʃɹɪlɪŋ sɔŋz ə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl ðɛmsɛlvz, ʃɑɹp wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɝ kwɪk əɹ sloʊ. ðeɪ nu mɛni sɔŋz, səm i ɹɛkəɡnaɪz fɹəm hoʊm, ðoʊ ɔfən ʌndɝ dɪfɹənt neɪmz ðən ðeɪ wɝ kɔld ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. "θɹi ɡɝlz ɪn ðə mɛdoʊ," fəɹ ɪnstəns, ðə tɪŋkɝz neɪmd "pɹɪɾi meɪdz dænsɪŋ," ən ðeɪ sɛd "ðə wɪn fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ" wɑz kɔld "hɑɹd ɹeɪn fɔlɪŋ" ɪn səm lænz ən "bɛɹɪnz ɹitʃɹit" ɪn ʌðɝz. wən i æskt, nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ, fəɹ "ðə tɪŋkɝ əz maɪ pɑts," ðeɪ fɛl ɔl oʊvɝ ðɛmsɛlvz læfɪŋ. ðeɪ nu ɪt, bʌɾ əz "tɔs ðə fɛðɝz."

It was hard to get a word with Egwene. Either she was talking with Ila, their heads together in a way that said no men were welcome, or she was dancing with Aram, swinging round and round to the flutes and fiddles and drums, to tunes the Tuatha'an had gathered from all over the world, or to the sharp, trilling songs of the Traveling People themselves, sharp whether they were quick or slow. They knew many songs, some he recognized from home, though often under different names than they were called in the Two Rivers. "Three Girls in the Meadow," for instance, the Tinkers named "Pretty Maids Dancing," and they said "The Wind From the North" was called "Hard Rain Falling" in some lands and "Berin's Retreat" in others. When he asked, not thinking, for "The Tinker Has My Pots," they fell all over themselves laughing. They knew it, but as "Toss the Feathers."

hi kəɾ ʌndɝstænd wɑntɪŋ tə dæns tə ðə pipəlz sɔŋz. bæk ɪn ɛmənz fil noʊ wʌn kənsɪɾɝd ɪm mɔɹ ðən ən æɾəkwət dænsɝ, bʌt ðiz sɔŋz tʌɡd əɾ ɪz fit, ən i θɔɾ i hæd nɛvɝ dænst soʊ lɔŋ, əɹ soʊ hɑɹd, əɹ soʊ wɛl ɪn ɪz laɪf. hɪpnɑɾɪk, ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪz blʌd paʊn ɪn ɹɪðəm tə ðə dʒɹʌmz.

He could understand wanting to dance to the People's songs. Back in Emond's Field no one considered him more than an adequate dancer, but these songs tugged at his feet, and he thought he had never danced so long, or so hard, or so well in his life. Hypnotic, they made his blood pound in rhythm to the drums.
