ɪt wɑz ðə sɛkən ivnɪŋ wən fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm pɛɹɪn sɔ wɪmən dæns tə səm ə ðə sloʊ sɔŋz. ðə faɪɝz bɝn loʊ, ən ðə naɪt hʌŋ kloʊs ɝaʊn ðə wæɡənz, ən fɪŋɡɝz tæpt ə sloʊ ɹɪðəm ɑn ðə dʒɹʌmz. fɝst wʌn dʒɹʌm, ðən ənʌðɝ, əntɪl ɛvɹi dʒɹʌm ɪn ðə kæmp kɛp ðə seɪm loʊ, ɪnsɪstən bit. ðəɹ wɑz saɪləns ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə dʒɹʌmz. ə ɡɝl ɪn ə ɹɛd dʒɹɛs sweɪɾ ɪndə ðə laɪt, lusənɪŋ əɹ ʃɔl. stʃɹɪŋz ə bidz hʌŋ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, ən ʃi hæd kɪkt ɔf əɹ ʃuz. ə flut bɪɡæn ðə mɛləɾi, weɪlɪŋ sɔfli, ən ðə ɡɝl dænst. aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt ɑɹmz spɹɛɾ əɹ ʃɔl bɪhaɪn hɝ; hɝ hɪps ənʒəleɪtɪd əz əɹ bɛɹ fit ʃʌfəl tə ðə biɾ ə ðə dʒɹʌmz. ðə ɡɝlz dɑɹk aɪz fæsən ɑn pɛɹɪn, ən əɹ smaɪl wɑz əz sloʊ əz əɹ dæns. ʃi tɝn ɪn smɔl sɝkəlz, smaɪlɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ət hɪm.

It was the second evening when for the first time Perrin saw women dance to some of the slow songs. The fires burned low, and the night hung close around the wagons, and fingers tapped a slow rhythm on the drums. First one drum, then another, until every drum in the camp kept the same low, insistent beat. There was silence except for the drums. A girl in a red dress swayed into the light, loosening her shawl. Strings of beads hung in her hair, and she had kicked off her shoes. A flute began the melody, wailing softly, and the girl danced. Outstretched arms spread her shawl behind her; her hips undulated as her bare feet shuffled to the beat of the drums. The girl's dark eyes fastened on Perrin, and her smile was as slow as her dance. She turned in small circles, smiling over her shoulder at him.

hi swɑloʊd hɑɹd. ðə hiɾ ɪn ɪz feɪs wɑz nɑt fɹəm ðə faɪɝ. ə sɛkənd ɡɝl dʒɔɪn ðə fɝst, ðə fɹɪnʒ ɑn ðɛɹ ʃɔlz ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪn taɪm tə ðə dʒɹʌmz ən ðə sloʊ ɹoʊteɪʃən ə ðɛɹ hɪps. ðeɪ smaɪld ət hɪm, ən i klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt hɔɹsli. hi wɑz əfɹeɪd tə lʊk ɝaʊnd; hɪz feɪs wɑz əz ɹɛɾ əz ə bit, ən ɛniwʌn u wɑz nɑt wɑtʃɪŋ ðə dænsɝz wɑz pɹɑbli læfɪŋ ət hɪm. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt.

He swallowed hard. The heat in his face was not from the fire. A second girl joined the first, the fringe on their shawls shaking in time to the drums and the slow rotation of their hips. They smiled at him, and he cleared his throat hoarsely. He was afraid to look around; his face was as red as a beet, and anyone who was not watching the dancers was probably laughing at him. He was sure of it.

əz kæʒəwəli əz i kəd mænədʒ, hi slɪɾ ɔf ðə lɔɡ əz ɪf i wɝ dʒʌst ɡɛɾɪŋ kʌmftəɹbəl, bʌɾ i kɛɹfəli ɛndəɾ ʌp lʊkɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə faɪɝ, əweɪ fɹəm ðə dænsɝz. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ laɪk ðəɾ ɪn ɛmənz fild. dænsɪŋ wɪð ðə ɡɝlz ɑn ðə ɡɹin ɑn ə fistdeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ivən kʌm kloʊs. fəɹ wʌns i wɪʃt ðət ðə wɪnd wəd pɪk ʌp, tə kul ɪm ɔf.

As casually as he could manage, he slid off the log as if he were just getting comfortable, but he carefully ended up looking away from the fire, away from the dancers. There was nothing like that in Emond's Field. Dancing with the girls on the Green on a feastday did not even come close. For once he wished that the wind would pick up, to cool him off.

ðə ɡɝlz dænst ɪndə hɪz fild ə vju əɡɛn, oʊnli naʊ ðeɪ wɝ θɹi. wʌn ɡeɪv ɪm ə slaɪ wɪŋk. hɪz aɪz dɑɹɾɪd fɹæntəkəli. laɪt, hi θɔt. wʌt də aɪ də naʊ? wʌt wəd ɹænd du? hi noʊz əbaʊt ɡɝlz.

The girls danced into his field of view again, only now they were three. One gave him a sly wink. His eyes darted frantically. Light, he thought. What do I do now? What would Rand do? He knows about girls.

ðə dænsɪŋ ɡɝlz læf sɔfli; bidz klɪkt əz ðeɪ tɔs ðɛɹ lɔŋ hɛɹ ɑn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ən i θɔɾ ɪz feɪs wəd bɝn ʌp. ðən ə slaɪtli oʊldɝ wʊmən dʒɔɪn ðə ɡɝlz, tə ʃoʊ ðɛm haʊ ɪt wɑz dʌn. wɪð ə ɡɹoʊn, hi ɡeɪv ʌp ɔltəɡɛðɝ ən ʃʌɾ ɪz aɪz. ivən bɪhaɪn ɪz aɪlɪdz ðɛɹ læftɝ tɔntɪɾ ən tɪkəld. ivən bɪhaɪn ɪz aɪlɪdz i kəd stɪl si ðɛm. swɛt biɾɪd ɑn ɪz fɔɹhɛd, ən i wɪʃt fəɹ ðə wɪnd.

The dancing girls laughed softly; beads clicked as they tossed their long hair on their shoulders, and he thought his face would burn up. Then a slightly older woman joined the girls, to show them how it was done. With a groan, he gave up altogether and shut his eyes. Even behind his eyelids their laughter taunted and tickled. Even behind his eyelids he could still see them. Sweat beaded on his forehead, and he wished for the wind.

əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ɹən ðə ɡɝlz dɪd nɑt dæns ðət dæns ɔfən, ən ðə wɪmən ɹɛɹli dɪd, ən əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ɛlaɪəs ɪt wɑz θæŋks tə pɛɹɪnz blʌʃəz ðət ðeɪ dɪd soʊ ɛvɹi naɪt ðɛɹæftɝ.

According to Raen the girls did not dance that dance often, and the women rarely did, and according to Elyas it was thanks to Perrin's blushes that they did so every night thereafter.

"aɪ hæv tə θæŋk ju," ɛlaɪəs toʊl hɪm, hɪz toʊn soʊbɝ ən sɑləm. "ɪts dɪfɹənt wɪð jə jʌŋ fɛloʊz, bʌɾ ət maɪ eɪdʒ ɪt teɪks mɔɹ ðən ə faɪɝ tə wɔɹm maɪ boʊnz." pɛɹɪn skaʊld. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɛlaɪəsəz bæk əz i wɔkt əweɪ ðət sɛɾ ivən ɪf nʌθɪŋ ʃoʊd, hi wɑz læfɪŋ ɪnsaɪd.

"I have to thank you," Elyas told him, his tone sober and solemn. "It's different with you young fellows, but at my age it takes more than a fire to warm my bones." Perrin scowled. There was something about Elyas's back as he walked away that said even if nothing showed, he was laughing inside.

pɛɹɪn sun lɝn bɛɾɝ ðən tə lʊk əweɪ fɹəm ðə dænsɪŋ wɪmən ən ɡɝlz, ðoʊ ðə wɪŋks ən smaɪlz stɪl meɪɾ ɪm wɪʃ i kʊd. wʌn wʊɾə bɪn ɔl ɹaɪt, meɪbi - bʌt faɪv əɹ sɪks, wɪð ɛvɹiwʌn wɑtʃɪŋ. . . . hi nɛvɝ dɪɾ ɪntaɪɝli kɑŋkɝ ɪz blʌʃəz.

Perrin soon learned better than to look away from the dancing women and girls, though the winks and smiles still made him wish he could. One would have been all right, maybe - but five or six, with everyone watching. . . . He never did entirely conquer his blushes.

ðən ɛɡwin bɪɡæn lɝnɪŋ ðə dæns. tu ʌv ðə ɡɝlz u hæd dæns ðət fɝs naɪt tɔt hɝ, klæpɪŋ ðə ɹɪðəm waɪl ʃi ɹɪpiɾɪd ðə ʃʌflɪŋ stɛps wɪð ə bɑɹoʊd ʃɔl sweɪɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ. pɛɹɪn stɑɹɾəd tə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ, ðən dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt wɑz waɪzɝ nɑt tə kɹæk ɪz tiθ. wən ðə ɡɝlz æɾəd ðə hɪp muvməns ɛɡwin stɑɹɾəd læfɪŋ, ən ðə θɹi ɡɝlz fɛl ɡɪɡəlɪŋ ɪndə wʌn ənʌðɝz ɑɹmz. bʌɾ ɛɡwin pɝsəvɪɹd, wɪð əɹ aɪz ɡlɪsnɪŋ ən bɹaɪt spɑts ə kʌlɝ ɪn əɹ tʃiks.

Then Egwene began learning the dance. Two of the girls who had danced that first night taught her, clapping the rhythm while she repeated the shuffling steps with a borrowed shawl swaying behind her. Perrin started to say something, then decided it was wiser not to crack his teeth. When the girls added the hip movements Egwene started laughing, and the three girls fell giggling into one another's arms. But Egwene persevered, with her eyes glistening and bright spots of color in her cheeks.

ɛɹæm wɑtʃt əɹ dænsɪŋ wɪð ə hɑt, hʌŋɡɹi ɡeɪz. ðə hænsəm jʌŋ tuætɑn hæd ɡɪvən əɹ ə stʃɹɪŋ ə blu bidz ðət ʃi wɔɹ ɔl ðə taɪm. wɝid fɹaʊnz naʊ ɹipleɪs ðə smaɪlz ilə hæd wɔɹn wən ʃi fɝs noʊɾəst əɹ ɡɹændsʌnz ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ɛɡwin. pɛɹɪn ɹizɑlv tə kip ə kloʊs aɪ ɑn jʌŋ mæstɝ ɛɹæm.

Aram watched her dancing with a hot, hungry gaze. The handsome young Tuatha'an had given her a string of blue beads that she wore all the time. Worried frowns now replaced the smiles Ila had worn when she first noticed her grandson's interest in Egwene. Perrin resolved to keep a close eye on young Master Aram.

wʌns i mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ɛɡwin əloʊn, bɪsaɪɾ ə wæɡən peɪntəɾ ɪn ɡɹin ən jɛloʊ. "ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ jɝsɛlf, ɑɹən ju?" hi sɛd.

Once he managed to get Egwene alone, beside a wagon painted in green and yellow. "Enjoying yourself, aren't you?" he said.

"waɪ ʃʊdn aɪ?" ʃi fɪŋɡɝd ðə blu bidz ɝaʊn əɹ nɛk, smaɪlɪŋ ət ðɛm. "wi doʊn ɔl əv tə wɝk ət biɪŋ mɪzɝəbəl, ðə weɪ jə du. doʊnt wi dɪzɝv ə lɪɾəl tʃæns tə ɛndʒɔɪ aʊɝsɛlvz?"

"Why shouldn't I?" She fingered the blue beads around her neck, smiling at them. "We don't all have to work at being miserable, the way you do. Don't we deserve a little chance to enjoy ourselves?"

ɛɹæm stʊd nɑt fɑɹ ɔf - hi nɛvɝ ɡɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ɛɡwin - wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst, ə lɪɾəl smaɪl ɑn ɪz feɪs, hæf smʌɡnəs ən hæf tʃælənʒ. pɛɹɪn loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs. "aɪ θɔt jə wɑntəd tə ɡɛt tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. jə woʊn lɝn tə bi ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hɪɹ."

Aram stood not far off - he never got far from Egwene - with his arms folded across his chest, a little smile on his face, half smugness and half challenge. Perrin lowered his voice. "I thought you wanted to get to Tar Valon. You won't learn to be an Aes Sedai here."

ɛɡwin tɔst əɹ hɛd. "æn aɪ θɔt jə dɪdn laɪk mi wɑntɪŋ tə bɪkʌm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ," ʃi sɛd, tu switli.

Egwene tossed her head. "And I thought you didn't like me wanting to become an Aes Sedai," she said, too sweetly.

"blʌɾ ən æʃəz, dʒju bɪliv wɝ seɪf hɪɹ? ɑɹ ðiz pipəl seɪf wɪð əs hɪɹ? eɪ feɪd kəd faɪn əs ɛnitaɪm."

"Blood and ashes, do you believe we're safe here? Are these people safe with us here? A Fade could find us anytime."

hɝ hæn tʃɹɛmbəld ɑn ðə bidz. ʃi loʊɝɾ ɪɾ ən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "wʌtɛvɝ ɪz gɑnə hæpən wɪl hæpən wɛðɝ wi liv tədeɪ əɹ nɛkst wik. ðæts wʌɾ aɪ bɪliv naʊ. ɛndʒɔɪ jɝsɛlf, pɛɹɪn. ɪt maɪt bi ðə læs tʃæns wi hæv."

Her hand trembled on the beads. She lowered it and took a deep breath. "Whatever is going to happen will happen whether we leave today or next week. That's what I believe now. Enjoy yourself, Perrin. It might be the last chance we have."

ʃi bɹʌʃt ɪz tʃik sædli wɪð əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ðən ɛɹæm hɛld aʊɾ ɪz hæn tə hɝ, ən ʃi dɑɹɾɪd tə hɪm, ɔlɹɛɾi læfɪŋ əɡɛn. əz ðeɪ ɹæn əweɪ tə wɛɹ fɪɾəlz sæŋ, ɛɹæm flæʃt ə tʃɹaɪʌmfənt ɡɹɪn oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət pɛɹɪn əz ɪf tə seɪ, ʃiz nɑt jʊɹz, bʌt ʃɪl bi maɪn.

She brushed his cheek sadly with her fingers. Then Aram held out his hand to her, and she darted to him, already laughing again. As they ran away to where fiddles sang, Aram flashed a triumphant grin over his shoulder at Perrin as if to say, she is not yours, but she will be mine.

ðeɪ wɝ ɔl fɔlɪŋ tu mʌtʃ ʌndɝ ðə spɛl ə ðə pipəl, pɛɹɪn θɔt. ɛlaɪəs ɪz ɹaɪt. ðeɪ doʊn əv tə tʃɹaɪ tə kənvɝt jə tə ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif. ɪt sips ɪndə ju.

They were all falling too much under the spell of the People, Perrin thought. Elyas is right. They don't have to try to convert you to the Way of the Leaf. It seeps into you.

ilə hæd teɪkən wʌn lʊk əɾ ɪm hʌɾəlɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə wɪnd, ðən pɹədust ə θɪk wʊl kloʊk aʊɾ ə hɝ wæɡən; ə dɑɹk ɡɹin kloʊk, hi wɑz pliz tə si, æftɝ ɔl ðə ɹɛdz ən jɛloʊz. əz i swʌŋ ɪt ɹaʊn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, θɪŋkɪŋ wʌɾ ə wʌndɝ ɪt wɑz ðət ðə kloʊk wɑz bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ hɪm, ilə sɛd pɹɪmli, "ɪt kəd fɪt bɛɾɝ." ʃi ɡlænst ət ði æks əɾ ɪz bɛlt, ən wən ʃi lʊkt ʌp əɾ ɪm əɹ aɪz wɝ sæɾ əbʌv əɹ smaɪl. "ɪt kəd fɪt mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ."

Ila had taken one look at him huddling out of the wind, then produced a thick wool cloak out of her wagon; a dark green cloak, he was pleased to see, after all the reds and yellows. As he swung it round his shoulders, thinking what a wonder it was that the cloak was big enough for him, Ila said primly, "It could fit better." She glanced at the axe at his belt, and when she looked up at him her eyes were sad above her smile. "It could fit much better."

ɔl ðə tɪŋkɝz dɪd ðæt. ðɛɹ smaɪlz nɛvɝ slɪpt, ðəɹ wɑz nɛvɝ ɛni hɛzəteɪʃən ɪn ðɛɹ ɪnvɪteɪʃənz tə dʒɔɪn əm fəɹ ə dʒɹɪŋk əɹ tə lɪsən tə ðə mjuzɪk, bʌt ðɛɹ aɪz ɔlweɪz tʌtʃt ði æks, ən i kəd fil wʌt ðeɪ θɔt. ə tul ə vaɪələns. ðəɹ ɪz nɛvɝ ɛni ɪkskjus fəɹ vaɪələns tə ənʌðɝ hjumən biɪŋ. ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif.

All the Tinkers did that. Their smiles never slipped, there was never any hesitation in their invitations to join them for a drink or to listen to the music, but their eyes always touched the axe, and he could feel what they thought. A tool of violence. There is never any excuse for violence to another human being. The Way of the Leaf.

səmtaɪmz i wɑntəd tə ʃaʊɾ ət ðɛm. ðəɹ wɝ tʃɹɑləks ɪn ðə wɝld, ən feɪdz. ðəɹ wɝ ðoʊz u wəd kʌt daʊn ɛvɹi lif. ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑz aʊt ðɛɹ, ən ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif wəd bɝn ɪn bælzəmənz aɪz. stʌbɝnli hi kəntɪnjud tə wɛɹ ði æks. hi tʊk tə kipɪŋ ɪz kloʊk θɹoʊn bæk, ivən wən ɪt wɑz wɪndi, soʊ ðə hæf-mun bleɪd wɑz nɛvɝ hɪɾən. naʊ ən əɡɛn ɛlaɪəs lʊkt kwɪtsɪkli ət ðə wɛpən hæŋɪŋ hɛvi əɾ ɪz saɪɾ ən ɡɹɪn ət hɪm, ðoʊz jɛloʊ aɪz simɪŋ tə ɹiɾ ɪz maɪnd. ðəɾ ɔlmoʊs meɪɾ ɪm kʌvɝ ði æks. ɔlmoʊst.

Sometimes he wanted to shout at them. There were Trollocs in the world, and Fades. There were those who would cut down every leaf. The Dark One was out there, and the Way of the Leaf would burn in Ba'alzamon's eyes. Stubbornly he continued to wear the axe. He took to keeping his cloak thrown back, even when it was windy, so the half-moon blade was never hidden. Now and again Elyas looked quizzically at the weapon hanging heavy at his side and grinned at him, those yellow eyes seeming to read his mind. That almost made him cover the axe. Almost.

ɪf ðə tuætɑn kæmp wɑz ə sɔɹs ə kɑnstən ɪɹɪteɪʃən, ət list ɪz dʒɹimz wɝ nɔɹməl ðɛɹ. səmtaɪmz i woʊk ʌp swɛɾɪŋ fɹəm ə dʒɹim ə tʃɹɑləks ən feɪdz stɔɹmɪŋ ɪndə ðə kæmp, ɹeɪnboʊ-kʌlɝd wæɡənz tɝnɪŋ tə bɑnfaɪɝz fɹəm hɝl tɔɹtʃɪz, pipəl fɔlɪŋ ɪn pulz ə blʌd, mɛn ən wɪmən ən tʃɪlʒɹən u ɹæn ən skɹimd ən daɪd bʌt meɪd noʊ ɛfɝt tə dɪfɛn ðɛmsɛlvz əɡɛnst slæʃɪŋ saɪð-laɪk sɔɹdz. naɪɾ æftɝ naɪɾ i boʊltəɾ əpɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk, pæntɪŋ ən ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ɪz æks bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪz ðə wæɡənz wɝ nɑɾ ɪn fleɪmz, ðət noʊ blʌɾi-mʌzəld ʃeɪps snɑɹəld oʊvɝ tɔɹn ən twɪstəd bɑɾiz lɪɾɝɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊnd. bʌt ðoʊz wɝ ɔɹɾənɛɹi naɪtmɛɹz, ən ɑdli kʌmfɝɾɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ weɪ. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ɛvɝ ə pleɪs fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn tə bi ɪn ɪz dʒɹimz, ɪt wɑz ɪn ðoʊz, bʌɾ i wɑz nɑt. noʊ bælzəmən. dʒʌst ɔɹɾənɛɹi naɪtmɛɹz.

If the Tuatha'an camp was a source of constant irritation, at least his dreams were normal there. Sometimes he woke up sweating from a dream of Trollocs and Fades storming into the camp, rainbow-colored wagons turning to bonfires from hurled torches, people falling in pools of blood, men and women and children who ran and screamed and died but made no effort to defend themselves against slashing scythe-like swords. Night after night he bolted upright in the dark, panting and reaching for his axe before he realized the wagons were not in flames, that no bloody-muzzled shapes snarled over torn and twisted bodies littering the ground. But those were ordinary nightmares, and oddly comforting in their way. If there was ever a place for the Dark One to be in his dreams, it was in those, but he was not. No Ba'alzamon. Just ordinary nightmares.

hi wɑz əwɛɹ ə ðə wʊlvz, ðoʊ, wən i wɑz əweɪk. ðeɪ kɛp ðɛɹ dɪstəns fɹəm ðə kæmps, ən fɹəm ðə kæɹəvæn ɑn ðə muv, bʌɾ i ɔlweɪz nu wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ. hi kəd fil ðɛɹ kəntɛmp fəɹ ðə dɑɡz ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə tuætɑn. nɔɪzi bists u hæd fɝɡɑɾən wʌt ðɛɹ dʒɔz wɝ fɔɹ, hæd fɝɡɑɾən ðə teɪst ʌv wɔɹm blʌd; ðeɪ maɪt fɹaɪɾən hjumənz, bʌt ðeɪ wəd slɪŋk əweɪ ɑn ðɛɹ bɛliz ɪf ðə pæk ɛvɝ keɪm. itʃ deɪ hɪz əwɛɹnəs wɑz ʃɑɹpɝ, mɔɹ klɪɹ.

He was aware of the wolves, though, when he was awake. They kept their distance from the camps, and from the caravan on the move, but he always knew where they were. He could feel their contempt for the dogs guarding the Tuatha'an. Noisy beasts who had forgotten what their jaws were for, had forgotten the taste of warm blood; they might frighten humans, but they would slink away on their bellies if the pack ever came. Each day his awareness was sharper, more clear.

dæpəl ɡɹu mɔɹ ɪmpeɪʃənt wɪð ɛvɹi sʌnsɛt. ðəɾ ɛlaɪəs wɑntəd tə də ðɪs θɪŋ ə teɪkɪŋ ðə hjumənz saʊθ meɪɾ ɪt wɝθ duɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪf ɪt mʌs bi dʌn, ðən lɛɾ ɪt bi dʌn. lɛt ðɪs sloʊ tʃɹævəl ɛnd. wʊlvz wɝ mɛn tə ɹoʊm, ən ʃi dɪd nɑt laɪk biɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə pæk soʊ lɔŋ. ɪmpeɪʃəns bɝn ɪn wɪnd, tu. hʌntɪŋ wɑz wɝs ðən pʊɹ hɪɹ, ən i dɪspaɪz lɪvɪŋ ɑn fil maɪs, sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ kʌbz tə stɔk waɪl lɝnɪŋ tə hʌnt, fɪt fud fəɹ ði oʊld, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ eɪbəl tə pʊl daʊn ə dɪɹ əɹ hæmstʃɹɪŋ ə waɪld ɑks. səmtaɪmz wɪn θɔt ðət bɝn hæd bɪn ɹaɪt; liv hjumən tʃɹʌbəlz tə hjumənz. bʌɾ i wɑz wɛɹi ʌv sətʃ θɔts wən dæpəl wɑz ɝaʊnd, ən ivən mɔɹ soʊ ɝaʊn hɑpɝ. hɑpɝ wɑz ə skɑɹɾ ən ɡɹɪzəl faɪɾɝ, ɪmpæsɪv wɪð ðə nɑlədʒ ə jɪɹz, wɪð ɡaɪl ðət mɔɹ ðən meɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ ʌv wɪtʃ eɪdʒ maɪɾ əv ɹɑb hɪm. fəɹ hjumənz i kɛɹd nʌθɪŋ, bʌt dæpəl wɪʃt ðɪs θɪŋ dʌn, ən hɑpɝ wəd weɪɾ əz ʃi weɪɾəd ən ɹʌn əz ʃi ɹæn. wʊlf əɹ mæn, bʊl əɹ bɛɹ, wʌtɛvɝ tʃælənʒd dæpəl wəd faɪn hɑpɝz dʒɔz weɪɾɪŋ tə sɛn ɪm tə ðə lɔŋ slip. ðət wɑz ðə hoʊl ə laɪf fəɹ hɑpɝ, ən ðət kɛpt wɪn kɔʃəs, ən dæpəl sim tə ɪɡnɔɹ ðə θɔts ə boʊθ.

Dapple grew more impatient with every sunset. That Elyas wanted to do this thing of taking the humans south made it worth doing, but if it must be done, then let it be done. Let this slow travel end. Wolves were meant to roam, and she did not like being away from the pack so long. Impatience burned in Wind, too. Hunting was worse than poor here, and he despised living on field mice, something for cubs to stalk while learning to hunt, fit food for the old, no longer able to pull down a deer or hamstring a wild ox. Sometimes Wind thought that Burn had been right; leave human troubles to humans. But he was wary of such thoughts when Dapple was around, and even more so around Hopper. Hopper was a scarred and grizzled fighter, impassive with the knowledge of years, with guile that more than made up for anything of which age might have robbed him. For humans he cared nothing, but Dapple wished this thing done, and Hopper would wait as she waited and run as she ran. Wolf or man, bull or bear, Whatever challenged Dapple would find Hopper's jaws waiting to send him to the long sleep. That was the whole of life for Hopper, and that kept Wind cautious, and Dapple seemed to ignore the thoughts of both.

ɔl ʌv ɪt wɑz klɪɹ ɪn pɛɹɪnz maɪnd. fɝvənli hi wɪʃt fəɹ keɪɛmlɪn, fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn ən tɑɹ vəlɑn. ivən ɪf ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ænsɝz, ðəɹ kəd bi ən ɛn tə ɪt. ɛlaɪəs lʊkt ət hɪm, ən i wɑz ʃʊɹ ðə jɛloʊ-aɪd mæn nu. pliz, lɛt ðəɹ bi ən ɛnd.

All of it was clear in Perrin's mind. Fervently he wished for Caemlyn, for Moiraine and Tar Valon. Even if there were no answers, there could be an end to it. Elyas looked at him, and he was sure the yellow-eyed man knew. Please, let there be an end.

ðə dʒɹim bɪɡæn mɔɹ plɛzənli ðən moʊst i hæɾ ə leɪt. hi wɑz əɾ ælsbɛt luhənz kɪtʃən teɪbəl, ʃɑɹpənɪŋ ɪz æks wɪð ə stoʊn. mɪstʃɹəs luhən nɛvɝ əlaʊd fɔɹdʒ wɝk, əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ðət smækt ʌv ɪt, tə bi bɹɔɾ ɪndə ðə haʊs. mæstɝ luhən ivən hæd tə teɪk əɹ naɪvz aʊtsaɪd tə ʃɑɹpən ðɛm. bʌt ʃi tɛndəɾ əɹ kʊkɪŋ ən nɛvɝ sɛɾ ə wɝɾ əbaʊt ði æks. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ ivən seɪ ɛniθɪŋ wən ə wʊlf ɛntɝd fɹəm dipɝ ɪn ðə haʊs ən kɝld ʌp bɪtwin pɛɹɪn ən ðə dɔɹ tə ðə jɑɹd. pɛɹɪn wɛn ɑn ʃɑɹpənɪŋ; ɪt wəd bi taɪm tə juz ɪt, sun.

The dream began more pleasantly than most he had of late. He was at Alsbet Luhhan's kitchen table, sharpening his axe with a stone. Mistress Luhhan never allowed forge work, or anything that smacked of it, to be brought into the house. Master Luhhan even had to take her knives outside to sharpen them. But she tended her cooking and never said a word about the axe. She did not even say anything when a wolf entered from deeper in the house and curled up between Perrin and the door to the yard. Perrin went on sharpening; it would be time to use it, soon.

əbɹʌpli ðə wʊlf ɹoʊz, ɹʌmbəlɪŋ dip ɪn ɪts θɹoʊt, ðə θɪk ɹʌf ə fɝ ɑn ɪts nɛk ɹaɪzɪŋ. bælzəmən stɛpt ɪndə ðə kɪtʃən fɹəm ðə jɑɹd. mɪstʃɹəs luhən wɛn ɑn wɪð əɹ kʊkɪŋ.

Abruptly the wolf rose, rumbling deep in its throat, the thick ruff of fur on its neck rising. Ba'alzamon stepped into the kitchen from the yard. Mistress Luhhan went on with her cooking.

pɛɹɪn skɹæmbəl tə hɪz fit, ɹeɪzɪŋ ði æks, bʌt bælzəmən ɪɡnɔɹd ðə wɛpən, kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə wʊlf, ɪnstɛd. fleɪmz dænst wɛɹ ɪz aɪz ʃəd bi. "ɪz ðɪs wʌt juv tə pɹətɛk ju? wɛl, aɪ hæv feɪs ðɪs bɪfɔɹ. mɛni taɪmz bɪfɔɹ."

Perrin scrambled to his feet, raising the axe, but Ba'alzamon ignored the weapon, concentrating on the wolf, instead. Flames danced where his eyes should be. "Is this what you have to protect you? Well, I have faced this before. Many times before."

hi kɹʊkəɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ, ən ðə wʊlf haʊld əz faɪɝ bɝst aʊɾ ʌv ɪts aɪz ən ɪɹz ən maʊθ, aʊɾ ʌv ɪts skɪn. ðə stɛntʃ ə bɝnɪŋ miɾ ən hɛɹ fɪl ðə kɪtʃən. ælsbɛt luhən lɪftəd ðə lɪɾ ɑn ə pɑɾ ən stɝd wɪð ə wʊɾən spun.

He crooked a finger, and the wolf howled as fire burst out of its eyes and ears and mouth, out of its skin. The stench of burning meat and hair filled the kitchen. Alsbet Luhhan lifted the lid on a pot and stirred with a wooden spoon.

pɛɹɪn dʒɹɑp ði æks ən dʒʌmp fɔɹwɝd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə biɾ aʊt ðə fleɪmz wɪð ɪz hænz. ðə wʊlf kɹʌmpəl tə blæk æʃ bɪtwin ɪz pɑmz. stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ʃeɪpləs paɪl ə tʃɑɹ ɑn mɪstʃɹəs luhənz klin-swɛp flɔɹ, hi bækt əweɪ. hi wɪʃt i kəd waɪp ðə ɡɹisi sʊt fɹəm ɪz hænz, bʌt ðə θɔɾ ə skɹʌbɪŋ ɪɾ ɔf ɑn ɪz kloʊðz tɝn ɪz stʌmək. hi snætʃt ʌp ði æks, ɡɹɪpɪŋ ðə hæft əntɪl ɪz nʌkəlz kɹækt.

Perrin dropped the axe and jumped forward, trying to beat out the flames with his hands. The wolf crumpled to black ash between his palms. Staring at the shapeless pile of char on Mistress Luhhan's clean-swept floor, he backed away. He wished he could wipe the greasy soot from his hands, but the thought of scrubbing it off on his clothes turned his stomach. He snatched up the axe, gripping the haft until his knuckles cracked.

"liv mi əloʊn!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. mɪstʃɹəs luhən tæp ðə spun ɑn ðə ɹɪm ə ðə pɑɾ ən ɹipleɪs ðə lɪd, hʌmɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf.

"Leave me alone!" he shouted. Mistress Luhhan tapped the spoon on the rim of the pot and replaced the lid, humming to herself.

"ju kænɑt ɹʌn fɹəm mi," bælzəmən sɛd. "ju kænɑt haɪd fɹəm mi. ɪf jə ɑɹ ðə wʌn, jə ɑɹ maɪn." ðə hit fɹəm ðə faɪɝz ə hɪz feɪs fɔɹs pɛɹɪn əkɹɔs ðə kɪtʃən əntɪl ɪz bæk keɪm ʌp əɡɛns ðə wɔl. mɪstʃɹəs luhən oʊpən ði ʌvən tə tʃɛk əɹ bɹɛd. "ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld wɪl kənsum ju," bælzəmən sɛd. "aɪ mɑɹk jə maɪn!" hi flʌŋ aʊɾ ɪz klɛntʃt hæn əz ɪf θɹoʊɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ; wən ɪz fɪŋɡɝz oʊpənd, ə ɹeɪvən stʃɹikt ət pɛɹɪnz feɪs.

"You cannot run from me," Ba'alzamon said. "You cannot hide from me. If you are the one, you are mine." The heat from the fires of his face forced Perrin across the kitchen until his back came up against the wall. Mistress Luhhan opened the oven to check her bread. "The Eye of the World will consume you," Ba'alzamon said. "I mark you mine!" He flung out his clenched hand as if throwing something; when his fingers opened, a raven streaked at Perrin's face.

pɛɹɪn skɹimd əz ðə blæk bik pɪɹst ɪz lɛft aɪ . . .

Perrin screamed as the black beak pierced his left eye . . .

. . . ən sæɾ ʌp, klʌtʃɪŋ ɪz feɪs, sɝaʊndəd baɪ ðə slipɪŋ wæɡənz ə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl. sloʊli hi loʊɝɾ ɪz hænz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ peɪn, noʊ blʌd. bʌɾ i kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪt, ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə stæbɪŋ æɡəni.

. . . and sat up, clutching his face, surrounded by the sleeping wagons of the Traveling People. Slowly he lowered his hands. There was no pain, no blood. But he could remember it, remember the stabbing agony.

hi ʃʌɾɝəd, ən sʌɾənli ɛlaɪəs wɑz skwɑɾɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪm ɪn ðə pɹidɔn, wʌn hæn aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt əz ɪf tə ʃeɪk ɪm əweɪk. bɪɑn ðə tʃɹiz wɛɹ ðə wæɡənz leɪ, ðə wʊlvz haʊld, wʌn ʃɑɹp kɹaɪ fɹəm θɹi θɹoʊts. hi ʃɛɹd ðɛɹ sɛnseɪʃənz. faɪɝ. peɪn. faɪɝ. heɪt. heɪt! kɪl!

He shuddered, and suddenly Elyas was squatting beside him in the predawn, one hand outstretched as if to shake him awake. Beyond the trees where the wagons lay, the wolves howled, one sharp cry from three throats. He shared their sensations. Fire. Pain. Fire. Hate. Hate! Kill!

"jɛs," ɛlaɪəs sɛd sɔfli. "ɪɾ ɪz taɪm. ɡɛɾ ʌp, bɔɪ. ɪts taɪm fəɹ əs tə ɡoʊ."

"Yes," Elyas said softly. "It is time. Get up, boy. It's time for us to go."

pɛɹɪn skɹæmbəld aʊɾ ə hɪz blæŋkəts. waɪl i wɑz stɪl bʌndəlɪŋ ɪz blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl, ɹən keɪm aʊɾ ə hɪz wæɡən, ɹʌbɪŋ slip fɹəm ɪz aɪz. ðə sikɝ ɡlænst ət ðə skaɪ ən fɹoʊz hæfweɪ daʊn ðə stɛps, hɪz hænz stɪl ɹeɪz tə hɪz feɪs. oʊnli hɪz aɪz muvd əz i stʌɾid ðə skaɪ ɪntɛnli, ðoʊ pɛɹɪn kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd wʌɾ i wɑz lʊkɪŋ æt. ə fju klaʊdz hʌŋ ɪn ði ist, ʌndɝsaɪdz stʃɹikt wɪð pɪŋk fɹəm ðə sʌn jɛt tə ɹaɪz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɛls tə si. ɹən sim tə lɪsən, əz wɛl, ən smɛl ði ɛɹ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saʊn ɪksɛp ðə wɪn ɪn ðə tʃɹiz ən noʊ smɛl bʌt ðə feɪn smoʊki ɹɛmnən ə læs naɪts kæmpfaɪɝz.

Perrin scrambled out of his blankets. While he was still bundling his blanketroll, Raen came out of his wagon, rubbing sleep from his eyes. The Seeker glanced at the sky and froze halfway down the steps, his hands still raised to his face. Only his eyes moved as he studied the sky intently, though Perrin could not understand what he was looking at. A few clouds hung in the east, undersides streaked with pink from the sun yet to rise, but there was nothing else to see. Raen seemed to listen, as well, and smell the air, but there was no sound except the wind in the trees and no smell but the faint smoky remnant of last night's campfires.

ɛlaɪəs ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ɪz oʊn skænti bɪlɔŋɪŋz, ən ɹən keɪm ðə ɹɛst ə ðə weɪ daʊn. "wi mʌs tʃeɪnʒ ðə dɝɛkʃən wi tʃɹævəl, maɪ oʊl fɹɛnd." ðə sikɝ lʊkt ənizəli ət ðə skaɪ əɡɛn. "wi ɡoʊ ənʌðɝ weɪ ðɪs deɪ. wɪl jə bi kʌmɪŋ wɪð ʌs?" ɛlaɪəs ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ən ɹən nɑɾəd əz ɪf i hæd noʊn ɔl əlɔŋ. "wɛl, teɪk kɛɹ, maɪ oʊl fɹɛnd. ðəɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt tədeɪ. . . ." hi stɑɹɾəd tə lʊk ʌp wʌns mɔɹ, bʌt pʊld ɪz aɪz bæk daʊn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹoʊz əbʌv ðə wæɡən tɑps. "aɪ θɪŋk ðə wæɡənz wɪl ɡoʊ ist. pɝhæps ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. pɝhæps wɪl faɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ, ən steɪ ðəɹ əwaɪl."

Elyas returned with his own scanty belongings, and Raen came the rest of the way down. "We must change the direction we travel, my old friend." The Seeker looked uneasily at the sky again. "We go another way this day. Will you be coming with us?" Elyas shook his head, and Raen nodded as if he had known all along. "Well, take care, my old friend. There is something about today. . . ." He started to look up once more, but pulled his eyes back down before they rose above the wagon tops. "I think the wagons will go east. Perhaps all the way to the Spine of the World. Perhaps we'll find a stedding, and stay there awhile."

"tʃɹʌbəl nɛvɝ ɛntɝz ðə stɛɾɪŋ," ɛlaɪəs əɡɹid. "bʌt ði oʊɡiɝ ɑɹ nʌn tu oʊpən tə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz."

"Trouble never enters the stedding," Elyas agreed. "But the Ogier are none too open to strangers."

"ɛvɹiwʌn ɪz oʊpən tə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl," ɹən sɛd, ən ɡɹɪnd. "bɪsaɪdz, ivən oʊɡiɝ əv pɑts ən θɪŋz tə mɛnd. kʌm, lɛɾ əs əv səm bɹɛkfəst, ən wɪl tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt."

"Everyone is open to the Traveling People," Raen said, and grinned. "Besides, even Ogier have pots and things to mend. Come, let us have some breakfast, and we'll talk about it."

"noʊ taɪm," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. "wi muv ɑn tədeɪ, tu. əz sun əz pɑsəbəl. ɪts ə deɪ fəɹ muvɪŋ, ɪt simz."

"No time," Elyas said. "We move on today, too. As soon as possible. It's a day for moving, it seems."

ɹən tʃɹaɪd tə kənvɪns ɪm tə ət list steɪ lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ fud, ən wən ilə əpɪɹd fɹəm ðə wæɡən wɪð ɛɡwin, ʃi æɾəd əɹ ɑɹɡjəməns, ðoʊ nɑɾ əz stʃɹɛnjuəsli əz əɹ hʌzbənd. ʃi sɛɾ ɔl ə ðə ɹaɪt wɝdz, bʌɾ əɹ pəlaɪtnəs wɑz stɪf, ən ɪt wɑz pleɪn ʃi wəd bi ɡlæd tə si ɛlaɪəsəz bæk, ɪf nɑɾ ɛɡwinz.

Raen tried to convince him to at least stay long enough for food, and when Ila appeared from the wagon with Egwene, she added her arguments, though not as strenuously as her husband. She said all of the right words, but her politeness was stiff, and it was plain she would be glad to see Elyas's back, if not Egwene's.

ɛɡwin dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs ðə ɹɪɡɹɛtfəl, saɪɾɛlɔŋ lʊks ilə ɡeɪv hɝ. ʃi æskt wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn, ən pɛɹɪn pɹipɛɹd hɪmsɛlf fəɹ əɹ tə seɪ ʃi wɑntəd tə steɪ wɪð ðə tuætɑn, bʌt wən ɛlaɪəs ɪkspleɪnd ʃi oʊnli nɑɾəd θɔtfəli ən hɝid bæk ɪndə ðə wæɡən tə ɡæðɝ əɹ θɪŋz.

Egwene did not notice the regretful, sidelong looks Ila gave her. She asked what was going on, and Perrin prepared himself for her to say she wanted to stay with the Tuatha'an, but when Elyas explained she only nodded thoughtfully and hurried back into the wagon to gather her things.

faɪnəli ɹən θɹu ʌp ɪz hænz. "ɔl ɹaɪt. aɪ doʊnt noʊ ðəɾ aɪ hæv ɛvɝ lɛɾ ə vɪzəɾɝ liv ðɪs kæmp wɪθaʊɾ ə fɛɹwɛl fist, bʌt. . . ." ənsɝteɪnli, hɪz aɪz ɹeɪz təwɔɹd ðə skaɪ əɡɛn. "wɛl, wi niɾ ən ɝli stɑɹɾ aʊɝsɛlvz, aɪ θɪŋk. pɝhæps wɪl iɾ əz wi dʒɝni. bʌɾ ət lis lɛɾ ɛvɹiwʌn seɪ ɡʊdbaɪ."

Finally Raen threw up his hands. "All right. I don't know that I have ever let a visitor leave this camp without a farewell feast, but. . . ." Uncertainly, his eyes raised toward the sky again. "Well, we need an early start ourselves, I think. Perhaps we will eat as we journey. But at least let everyone say goodbye."

ɛlaɪəs stɑɹɾəd tə pɹoʊtɛst, bʌt ɹən wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi hɝiɪŋ fɹəm wæɡən tə wæɡən, paʊndɪŋ ɑn ðə dɔɹz wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn əweɪk. baɪ ðə taɪm ə tɪŋkɝ keɪm, liɾɪŋ bɛlə, ðə hoʊl kæmp hæd tɝn aʊɾ ɪn ðɛɹ faɪnəst ən bɹaɪɾəst, ə mæs ə kʌlɝ ðət meɪd ɹən ən iləz ɹɛd-ænd-jɛloʊ wæɡən sim ɔlmoʊs pleɪn. ðə bɪɡ dɑɡz stʃɹoʊl θɹu ðə kɹaʊd wɪð ðɛɹ tʌŋz lɑlɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ maʊðz, lʊkɪŋ fəɹ sʌmwʌn tə skɹætʃ ðɛɹ ɪɹz, waɪl pɛɹɪn ən ði ʌðɝz ɛndʒjʊɹd hændʃeɪk æftɝ hændʃeɪk ən hʌɡ æftɝ hʌɡ. ðə ɡɝlz u hæd dænst ɛvɹi naɪt wəd nɑt bi kəntɛnt wɪð ʃeɪkɪŋ hænz, ən ðɛɹ hʌɡz meɪd pɛɹɪn sʌɾənli wɪʃ i wɑz nɑt livɪŋ æftɝ ɔl - əntɪl i ɹɪmɛmbɝd haʊ mɛni ʌðɝz wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ, ən ðən ɪz feɪs ɔlmoʊs mætʃt ðə sikɝz wæɡən.

Elyas started to protest, but Raen was already hurrying from wagon to wagon, pounding on the doors where there was no one awake. By the time a Tinker came, leading Bela, the whole camp had turned out in their finest and brightest, a mass of color that made Raen and Ila's red-and-yellow wagon seem almost plain. The big dogs strolled through the crowd with their tongues lolling out of their mouths, looking for someone to scratch their ears, while Perrin and the others endured handshake after handshake and hug after hug. The girls who had danced every night would not be content with shaking hands, and their hugs made Perrin suddenly wish he was not leaving after all - until he remembered how many others were watching, and then his face almost matched the Seeker's wagon.

ɛɹæm dʒɹu ɛɡwin ə lɪɾəl əsaɪd. pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt hɪɹ wʌɾ i hæd tə seɪ tə hɝ oʊvɝ ðə nɔɪz ʌv ɡʊdbaɪz, bʌt ʃi kɛpt ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd, sloʊli ət fɝst, ðən mɔɹ fɝmli əz i bɪɡæn tə dʒɛstʃɝ pliɾɪŋli. hɪz feɪs ʃɪftəd fɹəm pliɾɪŋ tə ɑɹɡjuɪŋ, bʌt ʃi kəntɪnjud tə ʃeɪk əɹ hɛd stʌbɝnli əntɪl ilə ɹɛskjuɾ əɹ wɪð ə fju ʃɑɹp wɝdz tə hɝ ɡɹændsʌn. skaʊlɪŋ, ɛɹæm pʊʃt əweɪ θɹu ðə kɹaʊd, əbændənɪŋ ðə ɹɛst ə ðə fɛɹwɛl. ilə wɑtʃt ɪm ɡoʊ, hɛzəteɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə kɔlɪŋ ɪm bæk. ʃiz ɹɪlivd, tu, pɛɹɪn θɔt. ɹɪlivd i dʌznt wɑnə ɡoʊ wɪð əs - wɪð ɛɡwin.

Aram drew Egwene a little aside. Perrin could not hear what he had to say to her over the noise of goodbyes, but she kept shaking her head, slowly at first, then more firmly as he began to gesture pleadingly. His face shifted from pleading to arguing, but she continued to shake her head stubbornly until Ila rescued her with a few sharp words to her grandson. Scowling, Aram pushed away through the crowd, abandoning the rest of the farewell. Ila watched him go, hesitating on the point of calling him back. She's relieved, too, Perrin thought. Relieved he doesn't want to go with us - with Egwene.

wən i hæd ʃeɪkən ɛvɹi hæn ɪn ðə kæmp ət list wʌns ən hʌɡd ɛvɹi ɡɝl ət lis twaɪs, ðə kɹaʊd muv bæk, oʊpənɪŋ ə lɪɾəl speɪs ɝaʊn ɹən ən ilə, ən ðə θɹi vɪzəɾɝz.

When he had shaken every hand in the camp at least once and hugged every girl at least twice, the crowd moved back, opening a little space around Raen and Ila, and the three visitors.

"ju keɪm ɪn pis," ɹən ɪntoʊnd, boʊɪŋ fɔɹməli, hænz ɑn ɪz tʃɛst. "dɪpɑɹt naʊ ɪn pis. ɔlweɪz wɪl əɹ faɪɝz wɛlkəm ju, ɪn pis. ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif ɪz pis."

"You came in peace," Raen intoned, bowing formally, hands on his chest. "Depart now in peace. Always will our fires welcome you, in peace. The Way of the Leaf is peace."

"pis bi ɑn jə ɔlweɪz," ɛlaɪəs ɹɪplaɪd, "æn ɑn ɔl ðə pipəl." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən æɾəd, "aɪ wɪl faɪn ðə sɔŋ, əɹ ənʌðɝ wɪl faɪn ðə sɔŋ, bʌt ðə sɔŋ wɪl bi sʌŋ, ðɪs jɪɹ əɹ ɪn ə jɪɹ tə kʌm. əz ɪt wʌns wɑz, soʊ ʃæl ɪt bi əɡɛn, wɝld wɪθaʊɾ ɛnd."

"Peace be on you always," Elyas replied, "and on all the People." He hesitated, then added, "I will find the song, or another will find the song, but the song will be sung, this year or in a year to come. As it once was, so shall it be again, world without end."

ɹən blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, ən ilə lʊkt kəmplitli flæbɝɡæstɪd, bʌɾ ɔl ði ʌðɝ tuætɑn mɝmɝɾ ɪn ɹɪplaɪ, "wɝld wɪθaʊɾ ɛnd. wɝld ən taɪm wɪθaʊɾ ɛnd." ɹən ən ɪz waɪf hɝidli sɛd ðə seɪm æftɝ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls.

Raen blinked in surprise, and Ila looked completely flabbergasted, but all the other Tuatha'an murmured in reply, "World without end. World and time without end." Raen and his wife hurriedly said the same after everyone else.

ðən ɪt ɹɪli wɑz taɪm tə ɡoʊ. ə fju læs fɛɹwɛlz, ə fju læst ædmənɪʃənz tə teɪk kɛɹ, ə fju læst smaɪlz ən wɪŋks, ən ðeɪ wɝ meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə kæmp. ɹən əkʌmpəniɾ əm əz fɑɹ əz ði ɛdʒ ə ðə tʃɹiz, ə pɛɹ ə ðə dɑɡz kəvɔɹɾɪŋ baɪ hɪz saɪd.

Then it really was time to go. A few last farewells, a few last admonitions to take care, a few last smiles and winks, and they were making their way out of the camp. Raen accompanied them as far as the edge of the trees, a pair of the dogs cavorting by his side.

"tʃɹuli, maɪ oʊl fɹɛnd, jə mʌs teɪk ɡɹeɪt kɛɹ. ðɪs deɪ. . . . ðəɹ ɪz wɪkədnəs lus ɪn ðə wɝld, aɪ fɪɹ, ən wʌtɛvɝ jə pɹitɛnd, jə ɑɹ nɑt soʊ wɪkəd ðəɾ ɪɾəl nɑt ɡɑbəl jə ʌp."

"Truly, my old friend, you must take great care. This day. . . . There is wickedness loose in the world, I fear, and Whatever you pretend, you are not so wicked that it will not gobble you up."

"pis bi ɑn ju," ɛlaɪəs sɛd.

"Peace be on you," Elyas said.

"æn ɑn ju," ɹən sɛd sædli.

"And on you," Raen said sadly.

wən ɹən wɑz ɡɔn, ɛlaɪəs skaʊld ət faɪndɪŋ ði ʌðɝ tu lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. "soʊ aɪ doʊn bɪliv ɪn ðɛɹ ful sɔŋ," hi ɡɹaʊld. "noʊ nid tə meɪk əm fil bæd baɪ mɛsɪŋ ʌp ðɛɹ sɛɹəmoʊni, wɑz ðɛɹ? aɪ toʊl jə ðeɪ sɛɾ ə stɔɹ baɪ sɛɹəmoʊni səmtaɪmz."

When Raen was gone, Elyas scowled at finding the other two looking at him. "So I don't believe in their fool song," he growled. "No need to make them feel bad by messing up their ceremony, was there? I told you they set a store by ceremony sometimes."

"ʌv kɔɹs," ɛɡwin sɛd dʒɛnli. "noʊ niɾ əɾ ɔl." ɛlaɪəs tɝn əweɪ mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf.

"Of course," Egwene said gently. "No need at all." Elyas turned away muttering to himself.

dæpəl, wɪnd, ən hɑpɝ keɪm tə ɡɹiɾ ɛlaɪəs, nɑt fɹɑlɪkɪŋ əz ðə dɑɡz hæd dʌn, bʌɾ ə dɪɡnəfaɪd miɾɪŋ ʌv ikwəlz. pɛɹɪn kɑt wʌt pæs bɪtwin ðɛm. faɪɝ aɪz. peɪn. hɑɹtfæŋ. dɛθ. hɑɹtfæŋ. pɛɹɪn nu wʌt ðeɪ mɛnt. ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ðeɪ wɝ tɛlɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪz dʒɹim. ðɛɹ dʒɹim.

Dapple, Wind, and Hopper came to greet Elyas, not frolicking as the dogs had done, but a dignified meeting of equals. Perrin caught what passed between them. Fire eyes. Pain. Heartfang. Death. Heartfang. Perrin knew what they meant. The Dark One. They were telling about his dream. Their dream.

hi ʃɪvɝɾ əz ðə wʊlvz ɹeɪnʒd aʊɾ əhɛd, skaʊɾɪŋ ðə weɪ. ɪt wɑz ɛɡwinz tɝn tə ɹaɪd bɛlə, ən i wɔk bɪsaɪd hɝ. ɛlaɪəs lɛd, əz juʒəwəl, ə stɛɾi, ɡɹaʊnd-iɾɪŋ peɪs.

He shivered as the wolves ranged out ahead, scouting the way. It was Egwene's turn to ride Bela, and he walked beside her. Elyas led, as usual, a steady, ground-eating pace.

pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk əbaʊɾ ɪz dʒɹim. hi hæd θɔt ðət ðə wʊlvz meɪɾ əm seɪf. nɑt kəmplit. æksɛpt. fʊl hɑɹt. fʊl maɪnd. jə stɪl stʃɹʌɡəl. oʊnli kəmplit wən jə æksɛpt.

Perrin did not want to think about his dream. He had thought that the wolves made them safe. Not complete. Accept. Full heart. Full mind. You still struggle. Only complete when you accept.

hi fɔɹs ðə wʊlvz aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd, ən blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. hi hæd nɑt noʊn i kəd də ðæt. hi dɪtɝmənd nɑt tə lɛɾ əm bæk ɪn əɡɛn. ivən ɪn dʒɹimz? hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf ðə θɔt wɑz ɪz əɹ ðɛɹz.

He forced the wolves out of his head, and blinked in surprise. He had not known he could do that. He determined not to let them back in again. Even in dreams? He was not sure if the thought was his or theirs.

ɛɡwin stɪl wɔɹ ðə stʃɹɪŋ ə blu bidz ɛɹæm hæd ɡɪvən hɝ, ən ə lɪɾəl spɹɪɡ ʌv sʌmθɪŋ wɪð taɪni, bɹaɪt ɹɛd livz ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, ənʌðɝ ɡɪft fɹəm ðə jʌŋ tuætɑn. ðəɾ ɛɹæm hæd tʃɹaɪd tə tɔk əɹ ɪndə steɪɪŋ wɪð ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl, pɛɹɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ. hi wɑz ɡlæd ʃi hæd nɑt ɡɪvən ɪn, bʌɾ i wɪʃt ʃi dɪd nɑt fɪŋɡɝ ðə bidz soʊ fɑnli.

Egwene still wore the string of blue beads Aram had given her, and a little sprig of something with tiny, bright red leaves in her hair, another gift from the young Tuatha'an. That Aram had tried to talk her into staying with the Traveling People, Perrin was sure. He was glad she had not given in, but he wished she did not finger the beads so fondly.

faɪnəli hi sɛd, "wʌt dɪd jə spɛn soʊ mʌtʃ taɪm tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt wɪð ilə? ɪf jə wɝn dænsɪŋ wɪð ðət lɔŋ-lɛɡəd fɛloʊ, jə wɝ tɔkɪŋ tə hɝ laɪk ɪt wɑz səm kaɪndə sikɹət."

Finally he said, "What did you spend so much time talking about with Ila? If you weren't dancing with that long-legged fellow, you were talking to her like it was some kind of secret."

"ilə wɑz ɡɪvɪŋ mi ædvaɪs ɑn biɪŋ ə wʊmən," ɛɡwin ɹɪplaɪɾ æbsənli. hi bɪɡæn læfɪŋ, ən ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə hʊɾɪd, deɪnʒɝəs lʊk ðəɾ i feɪl tə si.

"Ila was giving me advice on being a woman," Egwene replied absently. He began laughing, and she gave him a hooded, dangerous look that he failed to see.

"ædvaɪs! noʊbɑdi tɛlz əs haʊ tə bi mɛn. wi dʒʌst ɑɹ."

"Advice! Nobody tells us how to be men. We just are."

"ðæt," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ɪz pɹɑbli waɪ jə meɪk sətʃ ə bæd dʒɑb ʌv ɪt." ʌp əhɛd, ɛlaɪəs kækəld laʊdli.

"That," Egwene said, "is probably why you make such a bad job of it." Up ahead, Elyas cackled loudly.


tʃæptɝ twɛntieɪt


CHAPTER 28

fʊtpɹɪns ɪn ɛɹ


Footprints in Air

nɪneɪiv stɛɹɾ ɪn wʌndɝ ət wʌt leɪ əhɛd daʊn ðə ɹɪvɝ, ðə waɪt bɹɪdʒ ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn wɪð ə mɪlki ɡloʊ. ənʌðɝ lɛdʒənd, ʃi θɔt, ɡlænsɪŋ ət ðə wɔɹɾɝ ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʒʌst əhɛɾ ə hɝ. ənʌðɝ lɛdʒənd, ən ðeɪ doʊn ivən sim tə noʊɾəs. ʃi ɹizɑlv nɑt tə stɛɹ wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd si. ðəl læf ɪf ðeɪ si mi ɡeɪpɪŋ laɪk ə kʌntʃɹi bʌmpkɪn. ðə θɹi ɹoʊɾ ɑn saɪlənli təwɔɹd ðə feɪbəld waɪt bɹɪdʒ.

Nynaeve stared in wonder at what lay ahead down the river, the White Bridge gleaming in the sun with a milky glow. Another legend, she thought, glancing at the Warder and the Aes Sedai, riding just ahead of her. Another legend, and they don't even seem to notice. She resolved not to stare where they could see. They'll laugh if they see me gaping like a country bumpkin. The three rode on silently toward the fabled White Bridge.

sɪns ðət mɔɹnɪŋ æftɝ ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, wən ʃi hæd faʊn mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn ɑn ðə bæŋk ə ði ɑɹɪnɛl, ðəɹ hæd bɪn lɪɾəl ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv ɹil kɑnvɝseɪʃən bɪtwin əɹ ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðəɹ hæd bɪn tɔk, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ə sʌbstəns əz nɪneɪiv sɔ ɪt. mɔɪɹeɪnz ətɛmps tə tɔk əɹ ɪndə ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, fəɹ ɪnstəns. tɑɹ vəlɑn. ʃi wəd ɡoʊ ðɛɹ, ɪf nid bi, ən teɪk ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, bʌt nɑt fəɹ ðə ɹizənz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ θɔt. ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn hæd bɹɔt hɑɹm tə ɛɡwin ən ðə bɔɪz. . . .

Since that morning after Shadar Logoth, when she had found Moiraine and Lan on the bank of the Arinelle, there had been little in the way of real conversation between her and the Aes Sedai. There had been talk, of course, but nothing of substance as Nynaeve saw it. Moiraine's attempts to talk her into going to Tar Valon, for instance. Tar Valon. She would go there, if need be, and take their training, but not for the reasons the Aes Sedai thought. If Moiraine had brought harm to Egwene and the boys. . . .

səmtaɪmz, əɡɛnst əɹ wɪl, nɪneɪiv hæd faʊn hɝsɛlf θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv wʌɾ ə wɪzdəm kəd də wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ʌv wʌt ʃi kəd du. wɛnɛvɝ ʃi ɹilaɪzd wʌt wɑz ɪn əɹ hɛd, ðoʊ, ə flæʃ ʌv æŋɡɝ bɝn ɪɾ aʊt. ðə paʊɝ wɑz ə fɪlθi θɪŋ. ʃi wəɾ əv nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪt. ənlɛs ʃi hæd tə.

Sometimes, against her will, Nynaeve had found herself thinking of what a Wisdom could do with the One Power, of what she could do. Whenever she realized what was in her head, though, a flash of anger burned it out. The Power was a filthy thing. She would have nothing to do with it. Unless she had to.

ðə kɝst wʊmən oʊnli wɑntəd tə tɔk əbaʊt teɪkɪŋ əɹ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn fəɹ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. mɔɪɹeɪn wəd nɑt tɛl əɹ ɛniθɪŋ! ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə noʊ soʊ mʌtʃ.

The cursed woman only wanted to talk about taking her to Tar Valon for training. Moiraine would not tell her anything! It was not as if she wanted to know so much.

"haʊ dʒju min tə faɪn ðɛm?" ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd dɪmændɪŋ.

"How do you mean to find them?" she remembered demanding.

"æz aɪ hæv toʊl ju," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd wɪθaʊt bɑðɝɪŋ tə lʊk bæk ət hɝ, "aɪ wɪl noʊ wən aɪm kloʊs tə ðə tu hu hæv lɔs ðɛɹ kɔɪnz." ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə fɝs taɪm nɪneɪiv hæɾ æskt, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪz vɔɪs wɑz laɪk ə stɪl pɑn ðət ɹəfjuz tə ɹɪpəl noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mɛni stoʊnz nɪneɪiv θɹu; ɪt meɪd ðə wɪzdəmz blʌd bɔɪl ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi wɑz ɪkspoʊz tə ɪt. mɔɪɹeɪn wɛn ɑn əz ɪf ʃi kəd nɑt fil nɪneɪivz aɪz ɑn əɹ bæk; nɪneɪiv nu ʃi mʌs bi eɪbəl tə, ʃi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ soʊ hɑɹd. "ðə lɔŋɡɝ ɪt teɪks, ðə kloʊsɝ aɪ mʌs kʌm, bʌɾ əl noʊ. əz fəɹ ðə wʌn u stɪl əz ɪz toʊkən, soʊ lɔŋ əz hiz ɪɾ ɪn ɪz pəzɛʃən aɪ kən fɑloʊ hɪm əkɹɔs hæf ðə wɝld, ɪf nid bi."

"As I have told you," Moiraine replied without bothering to look back at her, "I will know when I am close to the two who have lost their coins." It was not the first time Nynaeve had asked, but the Aes Sedai's voice was like a still pond that refused to ripple no matter how many stones Nynaeve threw; it made the Wisdom's blood boil every time she was exposed to it. Moiraine went on as if she could not feel Nynaeve's eyes on her back; Nynaeve knew she must be able to, she was staring so hard. "The longer it takes, the closer I must come, but I will know. As for the one who still has his token, so long as he has it in his possession I can follow him across half the world, if need be."

"æn ðɛn? wʌt dʒju plæn wən juv faʊn ðɛm, ɛɛs sədaɪ?" ʃi dɪd nɑt fəɹ ə mɪnət bɪliv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wəd bi soʊ ɪntɛn ɑn faɪndɪŋ əm ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv plænz.

"And then? What do you plan when you've found them, Aes Sedai?" She did not for a minute believe the Aes Sedai would be so intent on finding them if she did not have plans.

"tɑɹ vəlɑn, wɪzdəm."

"Tar Valon, Wisdom."

"tɑɹ vəlɑn, tɑɹ vəlɑn. ðæts ɔl jə ɛvɝ seɪ, ən aɪm bɪkʌmɪŋ - "

"Tar Valon, Tar Valon. That's all you ever say, and I am becoming - "

"pɑɹɾ ə ðə tʃɹeɪnɪŋ jəl ɹəsiv ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, wɪzdəm, wɪl titʃ jə tə kəntʃɹoʊl jəɹ tɛmpɝ. jə kən də nʌθɪŋ wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ wən ɪmoʊʃən ɹulz jəɹ maɪnd." nɪneɪiv oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛn ɹaɪɾ ɑn. "læn, aɪ mʌst spik wɪð jə ə moʊmənt."

"Part of the training you will receive in Tar Valon, Wisdom, will teach you to control your temper. You can do nothing with the One Power when emotion rules your mind." Nynaeve opened her mouth, but the Aes Sedai went right on. "Lan, I must speak with you a moment."

ðə tu pʊt ðɛɹ hɛdz təɡɛðɝ, ən nɪneɪiv wɑz lɛft wɪð ə sʌlən ɡlaʊɝ ðət ʃi heɪɾəd ɛvɹi taɪm ʃi ɹilaɪzd ɪt wɑz ɑn əɹ feɪs. ɪt keɪm tu ɔfən əz ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɛfli tɝn əɹ kwɛstʃənz ɔf ɑntu ənʌðɝ sʌbʒɪkt, slɪɾ izəli baɪ hɝ kɑnvɝseɪʃənəl tʃɹæps, əɹ ɪɡnɔɹɾ əɹ ʃaʊts əntɪl ðeɪ ɛndəɾ ɪn saɪləns. ðə skaʊl meɪɾ əɹ fil laɪk ə ɡɝl u hæd bɪn kɑɾ æktɪŋ ðə ful baɪ sʌmwʌn ɪn ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl. ðət wɑz ə filɪŋ nɪneɪiv wɑz nɑt juz tə, ən ðə kɑm smaɪl ɑn mɔɪɹeɪnz feɪs oʊnli meɪɾ ɪt wɝs.

The two put their heads together, and Nynaeve was left with a sullen glower that she hated every time she realized it was on her face. It came too often as the Aes Sedai deftly turned her questions off onto another subject, slid easily by her conversational traps, or ignored her shouts until they ended in silence. The scowl made her feel like a girl who had been caught acting the fool by someone in the Women's Circle. That was a feeling Nynaeve was not used to, and the calm smile on Moiraine's face only made it worse.

ɪf oʊnli ðəɹ wɑz səm weɪ tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðə wʊmən. læn wəd bi bɛɾɝ baɪ hɪmsɛlf - ə wɔɹɾɝ ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə hændəl wʌt wɑz niɾəd, ʃi toʊl hɝsɛlf heɪstəli, filɪŋ ə sʌɾən flʌʃ; noʊ ʌðɝ ɹizən - bʌt wʌn mɛn ði ʌðɝ.

If only there was some way to get rid of the woman. Lan would be better by himself - a Warder should be able to handle what was needed, she told herself hastily, feeling a sudden flush; no other reason - but one meant the other.

ən jɛt, læn meɪɾ əɹ ivən mɔɹ fjʊɹiəs ðən mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn haʊ hi mænədʒ tə ɡɛɾ ʌndɝ əɹ skɪn soʊ izəli. hi ɹɛɹli sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ - səmtaɪmz nɑɾ ə dʌzən wɝdz ɪn ə deɪ - ən i nɛvɝ tʊk pɑɹɾ ɪn ɛni ʌv ðə . . . dɪskʌʃənz wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn. hi wɑz ɔfən əpɑɹt fɹəm ðə tu wɪmən, skaʊɾɪŋ ðə lænd, bʌɾ ivən wən i wɑz ðəɹ i kɛpt ə lɪɾəl tə wʌn saɪd, wɑtʃɪŋ əm əz ɪf wɑtʃɪŋ ə duəl. nɪneɪiv wɪʃt i wəd stɑp. ɪf ɪt wɑz ə duəl, ʃi hæd nɑt mænədʒ tə skɔɹ wʌns, ən mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd nɑɾ ivən sim tə ɹilaɪz ʃi wɑz ɪn ə faɪt. nɪneɪiv cʊɾə dʌn wɪθaʊɾ ɪz kul blu aɪz, wɪθaʊɾ ivən ə saɪlən ɑɾiəns.

And yet, Lan made her even more furious than Moiraine. She could not understand how he managed to get under her skin so easily. He rarely said anything - sometimes not a dozen words in a day - and he never took part in any of the . . . discussions with Moiraine. He was often apart from the two women, scouting the land, but even when he was there he kept a little to one side, watching them as if watching a duel. Nynaeve wished he would stop. If it was a duel, she had not managed to score once, and Moiraine did not even seem to realize she was in a fight. Nynaeve could have done without his cool blue eyes, without even a silent audience.

ðət hæd bɪn ðə weɪ ʌv ðɛɹ dʒɝni, fəɹ ðə moʊs pɑɹt. kwaɪət, ɪksɛpt wən əɹ tɛmpɝ ɡɑt ðə bɛst ə hɝ, ən səmtaɪmz wən ʃi ʃaʊɾəd ðə saʊn ə hɝ vɔɪs sim tə kɹæʃ ɪn ðə saɪləns laɪk bɹeɪkɪŋ ɡlæs. ðə læn ɪtsɛlf wɑz kwaɪət, əz ɪf ðə wɝld wɝ pɔzɪŋ tə kætʃ ɪts bɹɛθ. ðə wɪn moʊn ɪn ðə tʃɹiz, bʌɾ ɔl ɛls wɑz stɪl. ðə wɪn sim dɪstənt, tu, ivən wən ɪt wɑz kʌɾɪŋ θɹu ðə kloʊk ɑn əɹ bæk.

That had been the way of their journey, for the most part. Quiet, except when her temper got the best of her, and sometimes when she shouted the sound of her voice seemed to crash in the silence like breaking glass. The land itself was quiet, as if the world were pausing to catch its breath. The wind moaned in the trees, but all else was still. The wind seemed distant, too, even when it was cutting through the cloak on her back.

ət fɝs ðə stɪlnəs wɑz ɹɛsfəl æftɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət hæd hæpənd. ɪt simd əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt noʊn ə moʊmən ə kwaɪət sɪns bɪfɔɹ wɪntɝnaɪt. baɪ ði ɛn ə ðə fɝs deɪ əloʊn wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ, ðoʊ, ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ ən fɪdʒəɾɪŋ ɪn əɹ sæɾəl əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ən ɪtʃ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə hɝ bæk wɛɹ ʃi kəd nɑt ɹitʃ. ðə saɪləns sim laɪk kɹɪstəl dum tə ʃæɾɝ, ən weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə fɝs kɹæk pʊɾ əɹ tiθ ɑn ɛdʒ.

At first the stillness was restful after everything that had happened. It seemed as if she had not known a moment of quiet since before Winternight. By the end of the first day alone with the Aes Sedai and the Warder, though, she was looking over her shoulder and fidgeting in her saddle as if she had an itch in the middle of her back where she could not reach. The silence seemed like crystal doomed to shatter, and waiting for the first crack put her teeth on edge.

ɪt weɪɾ ɑn mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn, tu, əz aʊtwɝdli ənpɝɾɝbəbəl əz ðeɪ wɝ. ʃi sun ɹilaɪz ðæt, bɪniθ ðɛɹ kɑm sɝfəsəz, aʊɝ baɪ aʊɝ ðeɪ waʊn taɪɾɝ ən taɪɾɝ, laɪk klɑkspɹɪŋz biɪŋ fɔɹs tə ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ pɔɪnt. mɔɪɹeɪn sim tə lɪsən tə θɪŋz ðət wɝ nɑt ðɛɹ, ən wʌt ʃi hɝd pʊɾ ə kɹis ɪn əɹ fɔɹhɛd. læn wɑtʃt ðə fɔɹəst ən ðə ɹɪvɝ əz ɪf ðə lifləs tʃɹiz ən waɪd, sloʊ wɔɾɝ kæɹid ðə saɪnz ə tʃɹæps ən æmbʊʃɪz weɪɾɪŋ əhɛd.

It weighed on Moiraine and Lan, too, as outwardly unperturbable as they were. She soon realized that, beneath their calm surfaces, hour by hour they wound tighter and tighter, like clocksprings being forced to the breaking point. Moiraine seemed to listen to things that were not there, and what she heard put a crease in her forehead. Lan watched the forest and the river as if the leafless trees and wide, slow water carried the signs of traps and ambushes waiting ahead.

pɑɹɾ ə hɝ wɑz ɡlæd ðət ʃi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn u æpɹəhɛndəd ðət pɔɪzd-ɑn-ðə-bɹɪŋk fil tə ðə wɝld, bʌɾ ɪf ɪɾ əfɛktəd ðɛm, ɪt wɑz ɹil, ən ənʌðɝ pɑɹɾ ə hɝ wɑntəd nʌθɪŋ soʊ mʌtʃ əz fəɹ ɪt tə bi dʒʌst əɹ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ɪt tɪkəl ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɝ maɪnd, əz wən ʃi lɪsən tə ðə wɪnd, bʌt naʊ ʃi nu ðət ðət hæd tə də wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ən ʃi kəd nɑt bɹɪŋ hɝsɛlf tə ɛmbɹeɪs ðoʊz ɹɪpəlz ət ði ɛdʒ ə θɔt.

Part of her was glad that she was not the only one who apprehended that poised-on-the-brink feel to the world, but if it affected them, it was real, and another part of her wanted nothing so much as for it to be just her imagination. Something of it tickled the corners of her mind, as when she listened to the wind, but now she knew that that had to do with the One Power, and she could not bring herself to embrace those ripples at the edge of thought.

"ɪɾ ɪz nʌθɪŋ," læn sɛd kwaɪətli wən ʃi æskt. hi dɪd nɑt lʊk əɾ əɹ waɪl i spoʊk; hɪz aɪz nɛvɝ sis ðɛɹ skænɪŋ. ðɛn, kɑntʃɹədɪktɪŋ wʌɾ i hæd dʒʌst sɛd, hi æɾəd, "ju ʃəd ɡoʊ bæk tə jəɹ tu ɹɪvɝz wən wi ɹitʃ waɪtbɹɪdʒ, ən ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd. ɪts tu deɪnʒɝəs hɪɹ. nʌθɪŋ wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp jə ɡoʊɪŋ bæk, ðoʊ." ɪt wɑz ðə lɔŋɡəst spitʃ i meɪɾ ɔl ðət deɪ.

"It is nothing," Lan said quietly when she asked. He did not look at her while he spoke; his eyes never ceased their scanning. Then, contradicting what he had just said, he added, "You should go back to your Two Rivers when we reach Whitebridge, and the Caemlyn Road. It's too dangerous here. Nothing will try to stop you going back, though." It was the longest speech he made all that day.

"ʃi ɪz pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn, læn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd tʃaɪɾɪŋli. hɝ ɡeɪz wɑz ɛlswɛɹ, tu. "ɪɾ ɪz ðə dɑɹk wʌn, nɪneɪiv. ðə stɔɹm əz lɛft əs . . . fəɹ ə taɪm, ət list." ʃi ɹeɪzd wʌn hæn əz ðoʊ filɪŋ ði ɛɹ, ðən skɹʌbd ɪɾ ɑn əɹ dʒɹɛs ʌnkɑnʃəsli, əz ɪf ʃi hæd tʌtʃt fɪlθ. "hi ɪz stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ, haʊɛvɝ" - ʃi saɪd - "æn ɪz ɡeɪz ɪz stʃɹɔŋɝ. nɑɾ ɑn ʌs, bʌɾ ɑn ðə wɝld. haʊ mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ bɪfɔɹ hiz stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf tə. . . ."

"She is part of the Pattern, Lan," Moiraine said chidingly. Her gaze was elsewhere, too. "It is the Dark One, Nynaeve. The storm has left us . . . for a time, at least." She raised one hand as though feeling the air, then scrubbed it on her dress unconsciously, as if she had touched filth. "He is still watching, however" - she sighed - "and his gaze is stronger. Not on us, but on the world. How much longer before he is strong enough to. . . ."

nɪneɪiv hʌntʃt əɹ ʃoʊldɝz; sʌɾənli ʃi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil sʌmwʌn stɛɹɪŋ əɾ əɹ bæk. ɪt wɑz wʌn ɛkspləneɪʃən ʃi wəd dʒʌst əz sun ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd nɑt ɡɪvən hɝ.

Nynaeve hunched her shoulders; suddenly she could almost feel someone staring at her back. It was one explanation she would just as soon the Aes Sedai had not given her.

læn skaʊɾəd ðɛɹ pæθ daʊn ðə ɹɪvɝ, bʌt wɛɹ bɪfɔɹ i hæd tʃoʊzən ðə weɪ, naʊ mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd soʊ, əz ʃʊɹli əz ɪf ʃi fɑloʊd səm ənsin tʃɹæk, fʊtpɹɪns ɪn ɛɹ, ðə sɛn ə mɛmɹi. læn oʊnli tʃɛk ðə ɹut ʃi ɪntɛndəd, tə si ðəɾ ɪt wɑz seɪf. nɪneɪiv hæd ðə filɪŋ ðəɾ ivən ɪf i sɛɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt, mɔɪɹeɪn wəɾ ɪnsɪst ɑn ɪɾ ɛniweɪ. ən i wəd ɡoʊ, ʃi wɑz ʃʊɹ. stʃɹeɪt daʊn ðə ɹɪvɝ tə. . . .

Lan scouted their path down the river, but where before he had chosen the way, now Moiraine did so, as surely as if she followed some unseen track, footprints in air, the scent of memory. Lan only checked the route she intended, to see that it was safe. Nynaeve had the feeling that even if he said it was not, Moiraine would insist on it anyway. And he would go, she was sure. Straight down the river to. . . .

wɪð ə stɑɹt, nɪneɪiv pʊld aʊɾ ə hɝ θɔts. ðeɪ wɝ ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə waɪt bɹɪdʒ. ðə peɪl ɑɹtʃ ʃoʊn ɪn ðə sʌnlaɪt, ə mɪlki spaɪɾɝwɛb tu dɛləkət tə stænd, swipɪŋ əkɹɔs ði ɑɹɪnɛl. ðə weɪɾ ʌv ə mæn wəd bɹɪŋ ɪt kɹæʃɪŋ daʊn, mʌtʃ lɛs ðəɾ ʌv ə hɔɹs. ʃʊɹli ɪt wəd kəlæps ʌndɝ ɪts oʊn weɪɾ ɛni mɪnət.

With a start, Nynaeve pulled out of her thoughts. They were at the foot of the White Bridge. The pale arch shone in the sunlight, a milky spiderweb too delicate to stand, sweeping across the Arinelle. The weight of a man would bring it crashing down, much less that of a horse. Surely it would collapse under its own weight any minute.

læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn ɹoʊɾ ʌnkənsɝnədli əhɛd, ʌp ðə ɡlimɪŋ waɪɾ əpɹoʊtʃ ən ɑntu ðə bɹɪdʒ, hʊvz ɹɪŋɪŋ, nɑt laɪk stil ɑn ɡlæs, bʌt laɪk stil ɑn stil. ðə sɝfəs ə ðə bɹɪdʒ sɝɾənli lʊkt əz slɪk əz ɡlæs, wɛt ɡlæs, bʌɾ ɪt ɡeɪv ðə hɔɹsəz ə fɝm, ʃʊɹ fʊɾɪŋ.

Lan and Moiraine rode unconcernedly ahead, up the gleaming white approach and onto the bridge, hooves ringing, not like steel on glass, but like steel on steel. The surface of the bridge certainly looked as slick as glass, wet glass, but it gave the horses a firm, sure footing.

nɪneɪiv meɪd hɝsɛlf fɑloʊ, bʌt fɹəm ðə fɝst stɛp ʃi hæf weɪɾəd fəɹ ði ɪntaɪɝ stʃɹʌktʃɝ tə ʃæɾɝ ʌndɝ ðɛm. ɪf leɪs wɝ meɪɾ ʌv ɡlæs, ʃi θɔt, ɪt wəd lʊk laɪk ðɪs.

Nynaeve made herself follow, but from the first step she half waited for the entire structure to shatter under them. If lace were made of glass, she thought, it would look like this.

ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ ɔlmoʊst ɔl ðə weɪ əkɹɔs ðət ʃi noʊɾəst ðə tɛɹi smɛl ə tʃɑɹ θɪkənɪŋ ði ɛɹ. ɪn ə moʊmənt ʃi sɔ.

It was not until they were almost all the way across that she noticed the tarry smell of char thickening the air. In a moment she saw.

ɝaʊn ðə skwɛɹ ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə waɪt bɹɪdʒ paɪlz ə blækən tɪmbɝz, stɪl likɪŋ smoʊki θɹɛdz, ɹipleɪs hæf ə dʌzən bɪldɪŋz. mɛn ɪn pʊɹli fɪɾɪŋ ɹɛd junəfɔɹmz ən tɑɹnɪʃt ɑɹmɝ pətʃɹoʊl ðə stʃɹits, bʌt ðeɪ mɑɹtʃt kwɪkli, əz ɪf əfɹeɪɾ ə faɪndɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ, ən ðeɪ lʊkt oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz əz ðeɪ wɛnt. taʊnzpipəl - ðə fju hu wɝ aʊt - ɔlmoʊst ɹæn, ʃoʊldɝz hʌntʃt, əz ðoʊ sʌmθɪŋ wɝ tʃeɪsɪŋ ðɛm.

Around the square at the foot of the White Bridge piles of blackened timbers, still leaking smoky threads, replaced half a dozen buildings. Men in poorly fitting red uniforms and tarnished armor patrolled the streets, but they marched quickly, as if afraid of finding anything, and they looked over their shoulders as they went. Townspeople - the few who were out - almost ran, shoulders hunched, as though something were chasing them.

læn lʊkt ɡɹɪm, ivən fəɹ hɪm, ən pipəl wɔkt waɪɾ ə ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm, ivən ðə soʊlʒɝz. ðə wɔɹɾɝ snɪf ði ɛɹ ən ɡɹɪməst, ɡɹoʊlɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. ɪt wɑz noʊ wʌndɝ tə nɪneɪiv, wɪð ðə stɪŋk ə bɝn soʊ stʃɹɔŋ.

Lan looked grim, even for him, and people walked wide of the three of them, even the soldiers. The Warder sniffed the air and grimaced, growling under his breath. It was no wonder to Nynaeve, with the stink of burn so strong.

"ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz," mɔɪɹeɪn mʌmbəld. "noʊ aɪ kən si ðə pæɾɝn əntɪl ɪts woʊvən."

"The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills," Moiraine mumbled. "No eye can see the Pattern until it is woven."

ɪn ðə nɛks moʊmənt ʃi wɑz daʊn ɔf ɑldib ən spikɪŋ tə taʊnzfoʊk. ʃi dɪd nɑɾ æsk kwɛstʃənz; ʃi ɡeɪv sɪmpəθi, ən tə nɪneɪivz sɝpɹaɪz ɪɾ əpɪɹd dʒɛnjəwən. pipəl u ʃaɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm læn, ɹɛɾi tə hɝi fɹəm ɛni stʃɹeɪnʒɝ, stɑp tə spik wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn. ðeɪ əpɪɹd stɑɹɾəld ðɛmsɛlvz ət wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪ oʊpən ʌp, æftɝ ə fæʃən, ʌndɝ mɔɪɹeɪnz klɪɹ ɡeɪz ən suðɪŋ vɔɪs. ði ɛɛs sədaɪz aɪz sim tə ʃɛɹ ðə pipəlz hɝt, tə ɛmpəθaɪz wɪð ðɛɹ kənfjuʒən, ən tʌŋz lusənd.

In the next moment she was down off Aldieb and speaking to townsfolk. She did not ask questions; she gave sympathy, and to Nynaeve's surprise it appeared genuine. People who shied away from Lan, ready to hurry from any stranger, stopped to speak with Moiraine. They appeared startled themselves at what they were doing, but they opened up, after a fashion, under Moiraine's clear gaze and soothing voice. The Aes Sedai's eyes seemed to share the people's hurt, to empathize with their confusion, and tongues loosened.

ðeɪ stɪl laɪd, ðoʊ. moʊst ə ðɛm. səm dɪnaɪd ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɛni tʃɹʌbəl əɾ ɔl. nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl. mɔɪɹeɪn mɛnʃən ðə bɝn bɪldɪŋz ɔl ɝaʊn ðə skwɛɹ. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz faɪn, ðeɪ ɪnsɪstəd, stɛɹɪŋ pæst wʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt wɑnə si.

They still lied, though. Most of them. Some denied there had been any trouble at all. Nothing at all. Moiraine mentioned the burned buildings all around the square. Everything was fine, they insisted, staring past what they did not want to see.

wʌn fæt fɛloʊ spoʊk wɪð ə hɑloʊ hɑɹtinəs, bʌɾ ɪz tʃik twɪtʃt əɾ ɛvɹi nɔɪz bɪhaɪn hɪm. wɪð ə ɡɹɪn ðət kɛp slɪpɪŋ, hi kleɪmd ən oʊvɝtɝn læmp hæd stɑɹɾəd ə faɪɝ ðət spɹɛd wɪð ðə wɪn bɪfɔɹ ɛniθɪŋ kəd bi dʌn. wʌn ɡlæns ʃoʊd nɪneɪiv ðət noʊ bɝn stʃɹʌktʃɝ stʊɾ əlɔŋsaɪɾ ənʌðɝ.

One fat fellow spoke with a hollow heartiness, but his cheek twitched at every noise behind him. With a grin that kept slipping, he claimed an overturned lamp had started a fire that spread with the wind before anything could be done. One glance showed Nynaeve that no burned structure stood alongside another.

ðəɹ wɝ ɔlmoʊst əz mɛni dɪfɹən stɔɹiz əz ðəɹ wɝ pipəl. sɛvɹəl wɪmən loʊɝd ðɛɹ vɔɪsəz kənspɹətɔɹiəli. ðə tʃɹuθ ə ðə mæɾɝ wɑz ðəɹ wɑz ə mæn sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə taʊn mɛɾəlɪŋ wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ɪt wɑz taɪm tə hæv ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn; pæs taɪm, wɑz ðə weɪ ðeɪ sɔ ɪt, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt ðə mɛn sɛɾ əbaʊt tɑɹ vəlɑn. lɛt ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ sɛɾəl mæɾɝz.

There were almost as many different stories as there were people. Several women lowered their voices conspiratorially. The truth of the matter was there was a man somewhere in the town meddling with the One Power. It was time to have the Aes Sedai in; past time, was the way they saw it, no matter what the men said about Tar Valon. Let the Red Ajah settle matters.

wʌn mæn kleɪmd ɪt hæd bɪn ən ətæk baɪ bændəts, ən ənʌðɝ sɛɾ ə ɹaɪət baɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. "ðoʊz wʌnz gɑnə si ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən, jə noʊ," hi kənfaɪɾəd dɑɹkli. "ðeɪɹ ɔl oʊvɝ ðə pleɪs. dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ɛvɹi wʌn."

One man claimed it had been an attack by bandits, and another said a riot by Darkfriends. "Those ones going to see the false Dragon, you know," he confided darkly. "They're all over the place. Darkfriends, every one."

stɪl ʌðɝz spoʊk ə səm kaɪndə tʃɹʌbəl - ðeɪ wɝ veɪɡ əbaʊɾ ɪɡzækli wʌt kaɪnd - ðət hæd kʌm daʊnɹɪvɝ ɑn ə boʊt.

Still others spoke of some kind of trouble - they were vague about exactly what kind - that had come downriver on a boat.

"wi ʃoʊd ðɛm," ə nɛɹoʊ-feɪs mæn mʌɾɝd, skɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hæn təɡɛðɝ nɝvəsli. "lɛɾ əm kip ðət kaɪndə θɪŋ ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, wɛɹ ɪt bɪlɔŋz. wi wɛn daʊn tə ðə dɑks ən - " hi kʌɾ ɔf soʊ əbɹʌpli hɪz tiθ klɪkt. wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝɾ i skɝiɾ ɔf, piɹɪŋ bæk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ əɾ əm əz ɪf i θɔt ðeɪ maɪt tʃeɪs ɪm daʊn.

"We showed them," a narrow-faced man muttered, scrubbing his hand together nervously. "Let them keep that kind of thing in the Borderlands, where it belongs. We went down to the docks and - " He cut off so abruptly his teeth clicked. Without another word he scurried off, peering back over his shoulder at them as if he thought they might chase him down.

ðə boʊt hæd ɡɑɾən əweɪ - ðət mʌtʃ wɑz klɪɹ, ɪvɛntʃəwəli, fɹəm ʌðɝz - kʌɾɪŋ ɪts muɹɪŋz ən fliɪŋ daʊnɹɪvɝ oʊnli ðə deɪ bɪfɔɹ waɪl ə mɑb pɔɹɾ ɑntu ðə dɑks. nɪneɪiv wʌndɝɾ ɪf ɛɡwin ən ðə bɔɪz hæd bɪn ɑn bɔɹd. wʌn wʊmən sɛd ðəɾ ə ɡlimən hæd bɪn ɑn ðə boʊt. ɪf ðət hæd bɪn tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn. . . .

The boat had gotten away - that much was clear, eventually, from others - cutting its moorings and fleeing downriver only the day before while a mob poured onto the docks. Nynaeve wondered if Egwene and the boys had been on board. One woman said that a gleeman had been on the boat. If that had been Thom Merrilin. . . .

ʃi tʃɹaɪɾ əɹ əpɪnjən ɑn mɔɪɹeɪn, ðət səm ə ði ɛmənz fildɝz maɪɾ əv flɛɾ ɑn ðə boʊt. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ lɪsən peɪʃənli, nɑɾɪŋ, əntɪl ʃi wɑz dʌn.

She tried her opinion on Moiraine, that some of the Emond's Fielders might have fled on the boat. The Aes Sedai listened patiently, nodding, until she was done.

"pɝhæps," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd ðɛn, bʌt ʃi saʊndəd daʊtfəl.

"Perhaps," Moiraine said then, but she sounded doubtful.

ən ɪn stɪl stʊɾ ɪn ðə skwɛɹ, ðə kɑmən ɹum dɪvaɪɾəd ɪn tu baɪ ə ʃoʊldɝ-haɪ wɔl. mɔɪɹeɪn pɔzd əz ʃi stɛpt ɪndə ði ɪn, filɪŋ ði ɛɹ wɪð əɹ hænd. ʃi smaɪld ət wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz ʃi fɛlt, bʌt ʃi wəd seɪ nʌθɪŋ ʌv ɪt, ðɛn.

An inn still stood in the square, the common room divided in two by a shoulder-high wall. Moiraine paused as she stepped into the inn, feeling the air with her hand. She smiled at Whatever it was she felt, but she would say nothing of it, then.

ðɛɹ mil wɑz kənsumd ɪn saɪləns, saɪləns nɑɾ oʊnli ət ðɛɹ teɪbəl, bʌt θɹuaʊt ðə kɑmən ɹum. ðə hændfʊl ə pipəl iɾɪŋ ðəɹ kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn pleɪts ən ðɛɹ oʊn θɔts. ði ɪnkipɝ, dʌstɪŋ teɪbəlz wɪð ə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz eɪpɹən, mʌɾɝd tə hɪmsɛlf kəntɪnjuəli, bʌɾ ɔlweɪz tu loʊ tə bi hɝd. nɪneɪiv θɔɾ ɪt wəd nɑt bi plɛzən slipɪŋ ðɛɹ; ivən ði ɛɹ wɑz hɛvi wɪð fɪɹ.

Their meal was consumed in silence, silence not only at their table, but throughout the common room. The handful of people eating there concentrated on their own plates and their own thoughts. The innkeeper, dusting tables with a corner of his apron, muttered to himself continually, but always too low to be heard. Nynaeve thought it would not be pleasant sleeping there; even the air was heavy with fear.

əbaʊt ðə taɪm ðeɪ pʊʃt ðɛɹ pleɪts əweɪ, waɪp klin wɪð ðə læst skɹæps ə bɹɛd, wʌn ə ðə ɹɛd-junəfɔɹm soʊlʒɝz əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ. hi simd ɹisplɛndən tə nɪneɪiv, ɪn ɪz pik hɛlməɾ ən bɝnɪʃt bɹɛstpleɪt, əntɪl i tʊk ə poʊz dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə dɔɹ, wɪð ə hæn ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹɾ ən ə stɝn lʊk ɑn ɪz feɪs, ən juzd ə fɪŋɡɝ tə iz ɪz tu-taɪt kɑlɝ. ɪt meɪɾ əɹ θɪŋk ə sɛn bui tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə æk ðə weɪ ə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəlɝ ʃʊd.

About the time they pushed their plates away, wiped clean with the last scraps of bread, one of the red-uniformed soldiers appeared in the doorway. He seemed resplendent to Nynaeve, in his peaked helmet and burnished breastplate, until he took a pose just inside the door, with a hand resting on the hilt of his sword and a stern look on his face, and used a finger to ease his too-tight collar. It made her think of Cenn Buie trying to act the way a Village Councilor should.

læn spɛɹɾ ɪm wʌn ɡlæns ən snɔɹɾɪd. "məlɪʃə. jusləs."

Lan spared him one glance and snorted. "Militia. Useless."

ðə soʊlʒɝ lʊkt oʊvɝ ðə ɹum, lɛɾɪŋ ɪz aɪz kʌm tə ɹɛst ɑn ðɛm. hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ bɪfɔɹ stɑmpɪŋ oʊvɝ tə dɪmænd, ɔl ɪn ə ɹʌʃ, hu ðeɪ wɝ, wʌt ðɛɹ bɪznəs wɑz ɪn waɪtbɹɪdʒ, ən haʊ lɔŋ ðeɪ ɪntɛndəd tə steɪ.

The soldier looked over the room, letting his eyes come to rest on them. He hesitated, then took a deep breath before stomping over to demand, all in a rush, who they were, what their business was in Whitebridge, and how long they intended to stay.

"wi ɑɹ livɪŋ əz sun əz aɪ fɪnɪʃ maɪ eɪl," læn sɛd. hi tʊk ənʌðɝ sloʊ swɑloʊ bɪfɔɹ lʊkɪŋ ʌp ət ðə soʊlʒɝ. "ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ɡʊd kwin mɔɹɡeɪs."

"We are leaving as soon as I finish my ale," Lan said. He took another slow swallow before looking up at the soldier. "The Light illumine good Queen Morgase."

ðə ɹɛd-junəfɔɹmd mæn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ðən tʊk ə ɡʊd lʊk ət lænz aɪz ən stɛp bæk. hi kɑt hɪmsɛlf ɪmiɾiətli, wɪð ə ɡlæns ət mɔɪɹeɪn ən hɝ. ʃi θɔt fəɹ ə moʊmən ðəɾ i wɑz gɑnə də sʌmθɪŋ fulɪʃ tə kip fɹəm lʊkɪŋ ðə kaʊɝɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə tu wɪmən. ɪn əɹ ɪkspɪɹiəns, mɛn wɝ ɔfən ɪɾiəts ðət weɪ. bʌt tu mʌtʃ hæd hæpən ɪn waɪtbɹɪdʒ; tu mʌtʃ ənsɝɾənti hæɾ ɪskeɪp fɹəm ðə sɛlɝz ə mɛnz maɪnz. ðə mɪlɪʃəmən lʊk bæk ət læn ən ɹikənsɪɾɝd wʌns mɔɹ. ðə wɔɹɾɝz hɑɹd-pleɪn feɪs wɑz ɪkspɹɛʃənləs, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ ðoʊz koʊl blu aɪz. soʊ koʊld.

The red-uniformed man opened his mouth, then took a good look at Lan's eyes and stepped back. He caught himself immediately, with a glance at Moiraine and her. She thought for a moment that he was going to do something foolish to keep from looking the coward in front of two women. In her experience, men were often idiots that way. But too much had happened in Whitebridge; too much uncertainty had escaped from the cellars of men's minds. The militiaman looked back at Lan and reconsidered once more. The Warder's hard-planed face was expressionless, but there were those cold blue eyes. So cold.

ðə mɪlɪʃəmən sɛɾəld ɑn ə bɹɪsk nɑd. "si ðət jə du. tu mɛni stʃɹeɪnʒɝz ɝaʊn ðiz deɪz fəɹ ðə ɡʊɾ ə ðə kwinz pis." tɝnɪŋ ɑn ɪz hil i stɑmpt aʊɾ əɡɛn, pɹæktəsɪŋ ɪz stɝn lʊk ɑn ðə weɪ. nʌn ə ðə loʊkəlz ɪn ði ɪn sim tə noʊɾəs.

The militiaman settled on a brisk nod. "See that you do. Too many strangers around these days for the good of the Queen's peace." Turning on his heel he stomped out again, practicing his stern look on the way. None of the locals in the inn seemed to notice.

"wɛɹ ɑɹ wi ɡoʊɪŋ?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəɾ ə ðə wɔɹɾɝ. ðə muɾ ɪn ðə ɹum wɑz sətʃ ðət ʃi kɛpt əɹ vɔɪs loʊ, bʌt ʃi meɪd ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz fɝm, tu. "æftɝ ðə boʊt?"

"Where are we going?" Nynaeve demanded of the Warder. The mood in the room was such that she kept her voice low, but she made sure it was firm, too. "After the boat?"

læn lʊkt ət mɔɪɹeɪn, hu ʃʊk əɹ hɛd slaɪtli ən sɛd, "fɝst aɪ mʌs faɪn ðə wʌn aɪ kən bi ʃʊɹ ə faɪndɪŋ, ən ət pɹɛzən hiz sʌmwɛɹ tə ðə nɔɹθ ʌv ʌs. aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk ði ʌðɝ tu wɛnt wɪð ðə boʊɾ ɪn ɛni keɪs." ə smɔl, sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl tʌtʃt əɹ lɪps. "ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðɪs ɹum, pɝhæps ə deɪ əɡoʊ, noʊ mɔɹ ðən tu. əfɹeɪd, bʌt ðeɪ lɛft əlaɪv. ðə tʃɹeɪs wəd nɑɾ əv læstəd wɪθaʊt ðət stʃɹɔŋ ɪmoʊʃən."

Lan looked at Moiraine, who shook her head slightly and said, "First I must find the one I can be sure of finding, and at present he is somewhere to the north of us. I do not think the other two went with the boat in any case." A small, satisfied smile touched her lips. "They were in this room, perhaps a day ago, no more than two. Afraid, but they left alive. The trace would not have lasted without that strong emotion."

"wɪtʃ tu?" nɪneɪiv lin oʊvɝ ðə teɪbəl ɪntɛnli. "du jə noʊ?" ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, ðə slaɪɾəst ə moʊʃənz, ən nɪneɪiv sɛɾəld bæk. "ɪf ðəɹ oʊnli ə deɪ əɹ tu əhɛd, waɪ doʊnt wi ɡoʊ æftɝ əm fɝst?"

"Which two?" Nynaeve leaned over the table intently. "Do you know?" The Aes Sedai shook her head, the slightest of motions, and Nynaeve settled back. "If they're only a day or two ahead, why don't we go after them first?"

"aɪ noʊ ðeɪ wɝ hɪɹ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛɾ ɪn ðəɾ ɪnsʌfɝəbli kɑm vɔɪs, "bʌt bɪɑn ðəɾ aɪ kænɑt seɪ ɪf ðeɪ wɛn ist əɹ nɔɹθ əɹ saʊθ. aɪ tʃɹʌs ðeɪ ɑɹ smɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə hæv ɡɔn ist, təwɔɹd keɪɛmlɪn, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt noʊ, ən lækɪŋ ðɛɹ toʊkənz, əl nɑt noʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ əntɪl aɪm pɝhæps wɪðɪn hæf ə maɪl. ɪn tu deɪz ðeɪ cʊɾə ɡɔn twɛnti maɪlz, əɹ fɔɹɾi, ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən, ɪf fɪɹ ɝdʒ ðɛm, ən ðeɪ wɝ sɝɾənli əfɹeɪd wən ðeɪ lɛf hɪɹ."

"I know they were here," Moiraine said in that insufferably calm voice, "but beyond that I cannot say if they went east or north or south. I trust they are smart enough to have gone east, toward Caemlyn, but I do not know, and lacking their tokens, I will not know where they are until I am perhaps within half a mile. In two days they could have gone twenty miles, or forty, in any direction, if fear urged them, and they were certainly afraid when they left here."

"bʌt - "

"But - "

"wɪzdəm, haʊɛvɝ fɪɹfəl ðeɪ wɝ, ɪn wʌtɛvɝ dɝɛkʃən ðeɪ ɹæn, ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðəl ɹɪmɛmbɝ keɪɛmlɪn, ən ɪts ðəɹ əl faɪn ðɛm. bʌɾ əl hɛlp ðə wʌn aɪ kən faɪnd naʊ, fɝst."

"Wisdom, however fearful they were, in Whatever direction they ran, eventually they will remember Caemlyn, and it is there I will find them. But I will help the one I can find now, first."

nɪneɪiv oʊpən əɹ maʊθ əɡɛn, bʌt læn kʌɾ əɹ ɔf ɪn ə sɑf vɔɪs. "ðeɪ hæd ɹizən tə bi əfɹeɪd." hi lʊkt ɝaʊnd, ðən loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs. "ðɛɹ wɑz ə hæfmən hɪɹ." hi ɡɹɪməst, ðə weɪ hi hæɾ ɪn ðə skwɛɹ. "aɪ kən stɪl smɛl ɪm ɛvɹiwɛɹ."

Nynaeve opened her mouth again, but Lan cut her off in a soft voice. "They had reason to be afraid." He looked around, then lowered his voice. "There was a Halfman here." He grimaced, the way he had in the square. "I can still smell him everywhere."

mɔɪɹeɪn saɪd. "aɪ wɪl kip hoʊp əntɪl aɪ noʊ ɪts ɡɔn. aɪ ɹəfjuz tə bɪliv ðə dɑɹk wʌn kən wɪn soʊ izəli. əl faɪn ɔl θɹi ʌv əm əlaɪv ən wɛl. aɪ mʌs bɪliv ɪt."

Moiraine sighed. "I will keep hope until I know it is gone. I refuse to believe the Dark One can win so easily. I will find all three of them alive and well. I must believe it."

"aɪ wɑnə faɪn ðə bɔɪz, tu," nɪneɪiv sɛd, "bʌt wʌɾ əbaʊɾ ɛɡwin? jə nɛvɝ ivən mɛnʃən hɝ, ən jə ɪɡnɔɹ mi wən aɪ æsk. aɪ θɔt jə wɝ gɑnə teɪk əɹ ɔf tə" - ʃi ɡlænst ət ði ʌðɝ teɪbəlz, ən loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs - "tə tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"I want to find the boys, too," Nynaeve said, "but what about Egwene? You never even mention her, and you ignore me when I ask. I thought you were going to take her off to" - she glanced at the other tables, and lowered her voice - "to Tar Valon."

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stʌɾid ðə teɪbəltɑp fəɹ ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ ɹeɪzɪŋ əɹ aɪz tə nɪneɪivz, ən wən ʃi dɪd, nɪneɪiv stɑɹɾəd bæk fɹəm ə flæʃ ʌv æŋɡɝ ðəɾ ɔlmoʊst sim tə meɪk mɔɪɹeɪnz aɪz ɡloʊ. ðən əɹ bæk stɪfənd, hɝ oʊn æŋɡɝ ɹaɪzɪŋ, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd seɪ ə wɝd, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ spoʊk koʊldli.

The Aes Sedai studied the tabletop for a moment before raising her eyes to Nynaeve's, and when she did, Nynaeve started back from a flash of anger that almost seemed to make Moiraine's eyes glow. Then her back stiffened, her own anger rising, but before she could say a word, the Aes Sedai spoke coldly.

"aɪ hoʊp tə faɪn ɛɡwin əlaɪv ən wɛl, tu. aɪ də nɑɾ izəli ɡɪv ʌp jʌŋ wɪmən wɪð ðət mʌtʃ əbɪləɾi wʌns aɪ hæv faʊn ðɛm. bʌɾ ɪɾəl bi əz ðə wil wivz."

"I hope to find Egwene alive and well, too. I do not easily give up young women with that much ability once I have found them. But it will be as the Wheel weaves."

nɪneɪiv fɛlt ə koʊl bɔl ɪn ðə pɪɾ ə hɝ stʌmək. æm aɪ wʌn ə ðoʊz jʌŋ wɪmən jə woʊnt ɡɪv ʌp? wɪl si əbaʊt ðæt, ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə laɪt bɝn ju, wɪl si əbaʊt ðæt!

Nynaeve felt a cold ball in the pit of her stomach. Am I one of those young women you won't give up? We'll see about that, Aes Sedai. The Light burn you, we'll see about that!

ðə mil wɑz fɪnɪʃt ɪn saɪləns, ən ɪt wɑz ə saɪlən θɹi hu ɹoʊd θɹu ðə ɡeɪts ən daʊn ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd. mɔɪɹeɪnz aɪz sɝtʃt ðə hɝaɪzən tə ðə nɔɹθist. bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ðə smoʊk-steɪn taʊn ʌv waɪtbɹɪdʒ kaʊɝd.

The meal was finished in silence, and it was a silent three who rode through the gates and down the Caemlyn Road. Moiraine's eyes searched the horizon to the northeast. Behind them, the smoke-stained town of Whitebridge cowered.


tʃæptɝ twɛntinaɪn


CHAPTER 29

aɪz wɪθaʊt pɪɾi


Eyes Without Pity

ɛlaɪəs pʊʃt fəɹ spiɾ əkɹɔs ðə bɹaʊn ɡɹæs flætlæn əz ɪf tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ʌp fəɹ ðə taɪm spɛnt wɪð ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl, sɛɾɪŋ ə peɪs saʊθwɝd ðət hæɾ ivən bɛlə ɡɹeɪtfəl tə stɑp wən twaɪlaɪt dipənd. dɪspaɪɾ ɪz dɪzaɪɝ fəɹ heɪst, ðoʊ, hi tʊk pɹikɔʃənz i hæd nɑt teɪkən bɪfɔɹ. ət naɪt ðeɪ hæɾ ə faɪɝ oʊnli ɪf ðəɹ wɑz dɛd wʊɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hi wəd nɑt lɛɾ əm bɹeɪk soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə twɪɡ ɔf ʌv ə stændɪŋ tʃɹi. ðə faɪɝz i meɪd wɝ smɔl, ən ɔlweɪz hɪɾən ɪn ə pɪt kɛɹfəli dʌɡ wɛɹ i hæd kʌɾ əweɪ ə plʌɡ ʌv sɑd. əz sun əz ðɛɹ mil wɑz pɹipɛɹd, hi bɛɹid ðə koʊlz ən ɹipleɪs ðə plʌɡ. bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ sɛɾ aʊɾ əɡɛn ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ fɔls dɔn, hi wɛn oʊvɝ ðə kæmpsaɪɾ ɪntʃ baɪ ɪntʃ tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ðəɾ ɛniwʌn hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn ðɛɹ. hi ivən ɹaɪɾɪd oʊvɝtɝn ɹɑks ən stʃɹeɪɾənd bɛnt-daʊn widz. hi dɪɾ ɪt kwɪkli, nɛvɝ teɪkɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ə fju mɪnəts, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt liv əntɪl i wɑz sæɾəsfaɪd.

Elyas pushed for speed across the brown grass flatland as if trying to make up for the time spent with the Traveling People, setting a pace southward that had even Bela grateful to stop when twilight deepened. Despite his desire for haste, though, he took precautions he had not taken before. At night they had a fire only if there was dead wood already on the ground. He would not let them break so much as a twig off of a standing tree. The fires he made were small, and always hidden in a pit carefully dug where he had cut away a plug of sod. As soon as their meal was prepared, he buried the coals and replaced the plug. Before they set out again in the gray false dawn, he went over the campsite inch by inch to make sure there was no sign that anyone had ever been there. He even righted overturned rocks and straightened bent-down weeds. He did it quickly, never taking more than a few minutes, but they did not leave until he was satisfied.

pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðə pɹikɔʃənz wɝ mʌtʃ ɡʊɾ əɡɛns dʒɹimz, bʌt wən i bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk ʌv wʌt ðeɪ maɪt bi ɡʊɾ əɡɛnst, hi wɪʃt ɪt wɝ oʊnli ðə dʒɹimz. ðə fɝs taɪm, ɛɡwin æskt æŋkʃəsli ɪf ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ bæk, bʌɾ ɛlaɪəs oʊnli ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ən ɝdʒd əm ɑn. pɛɹɪn sɛd nʌθɪŋ. hi nu ðəɹ wɝ noʊ tʃɹɑləks kloʊz; ðə wʊlvz sɛntɪɾ oʊnli ɡɹæs ən tʃɹiz ən smɔl ænəməlz. ɪt wɑz nɑt fɪɹ ə tʃɹɑləks ðət dʒɹoʊv ɛlaɪəs, bʌt ðət sʌmθɪŋ ɛls ʌv wɪtʃ ivən ɛlaɪəs wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ. ðə wʊlvz nu nʌθɪŋ ʌv wʌɾ ɪt wɑz, bʌt ðeɪ sɛnst ɛlaɪəsəz ɝdʒənt wɛɹinɪs, ən ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə skaʊɾ əz ɪf deɪnʒɝ ɹæn ət ðɛɹ hilz əɹ weɪɾəd ɪn æmbʊʃ oʊvɝ ðə nɛkst ɹaɪz.

Perrin did not think the precautions were much good against dreams, but when he began to think of what they might be good against, he wished it were only the dreams. The first time, Egwene asked anxiously if the Trollocs were back, but Elyas only shook his head and urged them on. Perrin said nothing. He knew there were no Trollocs close; the wolves scented only grass and trees and small animals. It was not fear of Trollocs that drove Elyas, but that something else of which even Elyas was not sure. The wolves knew nothing of what it was, but they sensed Elyas's urgent wariness, and they began to scout as if danger ran at their heels or waited in ambush over the next rise.

ðə læn bɪkeɪm lɔŋ, ɹoʊlɪŋ kɹɛsts, tu loʊ tə bi kɔl hɪlz, ɹaɪzɪŋ əkɹɔs ðɛɹ pæθ. ə kɑɹpəɾ ə tʌf ɡɹæs, stɪl wɪntɝ sɪɹ ən dɑɾəd wɪð ɹæŋk widz, spɹɛd bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, ɹɪpəl baɪ ən ist wɪn ðət hæd nʌθɪŋ tə kʌɾ ɪt fəɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz. ðə ɡɹoʊvz ə tʃɹiz ɡɹu mɔɹ skæɾɝd. ðə sʌn ɹoʊz ɹɪlʌktənli, wɪθaʊt wɔɹmθ.

The land became long, rolling crests, too low to be called hills, rising across their path. A carpet of tough grass, still winter sere and dotted with rank weeds, spread before them, rippled by an east wind that had nothing to cut it for a hundred miles. The groves of trees grew more scattered. The sun rose reluctantly, without warmth.

əmʌŋ ðə skwɑt ɹɪdʒəz ɛlaɪəs fɑloʊd ðə kɑntʊɹz ə ðə læn əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl, ən i əvɔɪɾəd tɑpɪŋ ðə ɹaɪzəz wɛnɛvɝ pɑsəbəl. hi sɛldəm tɔkt, ən wən i dɪd. . . .

Among the squat ridges Elyas followed the contours of the land as much as possible, and he avoided topping the rises whenever possible. He seldom talked, and when he did. . . .

"ju noʊ haʊ lɔŋ ðɪs ɪz teɪkɪŋ, ɡoʊɪŋ ɝaʊn ɛvɹi blʌɾi lɪɾəl hɪl laɪk ðɪs? blʌɾ ən æʃəz! əl bi tɪl sʌmɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ jə ɔf maɪ hænz. noʊ, wi kæn dʒʌst ɡoʊ ɪn ə stʃɹeɪt laɪn! haʊ mɛni taɪmz də aɪ hæv tə tɛl ju? juv ɛni aɪdiə, ivən ðə feɪntəst, haʊ ə mæn stænz aʊɾ ɑn ə ɹɪdʒəlaɪn ɪn kʌntʃɹi laɪk ðɪs? bɝn mi, bʌt wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ əz mʌtʃ əz fɔɹwɝd. wɪɡəlɪŋ laɪk ə sneɪk. aɪ kəd muv fæstɝ wɪð maɪ fit taɪd. wɛl, jə gɑnə stɛɹ ət mi, əɹ jə ɡoʊɪŋ tə wɔk?"

"You know how long this is taking, going around every bloody little hill like this? Blood and ashes! I'll be till summer getting you off my hands. No, we can't just go in a straight line! How many times do I have to tell you? You have any idea, even the faintest, how a man stands out on a ridgeline in country like this? Burn me, but we're going back and forth as much as forward. Wiggling like a snake. I could move faster with my feet tied. Well, you going to stare at me, or you going to walk?"

pɛɹɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ɡlænsɪz wɪð ɛɡwin. ʃi stʌk əɹ tʌŋ aʊɾ əɾ ɛlaɪəsəz bæk. niðɝ ə ðɛm sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ. ðə wʌn taɪm ɛɡwin hæd pɹətɛstəd ðəɾ ɛlaɪəs wɑz ðə wʌn u wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ ɝaʊn ðə hɪlz ən i ʃəd nɑt bleɪm ðɛm, ɪt ɡɑɾ əɹ ə lɛktʃɝ ɑn haʊ saʊn kæɹid, dɪlɪvɝɾ ɪn ə ɡɹaʊl ðət cʊɾə bɪn hɝɾ ə maɪl ɔf. hi ɡeɪv ðə lɛktʃɝ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ən i nɛvɝ ivən sloʊd tə ɡɪv ɪt.

Perrin exchanged glances with Egwene. She stuck her tongue out at Elyas's back. Neither of them said anything. The one time Egwene had protested that Elyas was the one who wanted to go around the hills and he should not blame them, it got her a lecture on how sound carried, delivered in a growl that could have been heard a mile off. He gave the lecture over his shoulder, and he never even slowed to give it.

wɛðɝ i wɑz tɔkɪŋ əɹ nɑt, ɛlaɪəsəz aɪz sɝtʃt ɔl ɝaʊn ðɛm, səmtaɪmz stɛɹɪŋ əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ sʌmθɪŋ tə si ɪksɛp ðə seɪm kɔɹs ɡɹæs ðət wɑz ʌndɝ ðɛɹ fit. ɪf i dɪd si ɛniθɪŋ, pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt, ən niðɝ kəd ðə wʊlvz. ɛlaɪəsəz fɔɹhɛd ɡɹu ɛkstʃɹə fɝoʊz, bʌɾ i wəd nɑɾ ɪkspleɪn, nɑt waɪ ðeɪ hæd tə hɝi, nɑt wʌɾ i wɑz əfɹeɪd wɑz hʌntɪŋ ðɛm.

Whether he was talking or not, Elyas's eyes searched all around them, sometimes staring as if there were something to see except the same coarse grass that was under their feet. If he did see anything, Perrin could not, and neither could the wolves. Elyas's forehead grew extra furrows, but he would not explain, not why they had to hurry, not what he was afraid was hunting them.

səmtaɪmz ə lɔŋɡɝ ɹɪdʒ ðən juʒəwəl leɪ əkɹɔs ðɛɹ pæθ, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ maɪlz ən maɪlz tə ist ən wɛst. ivən ɛlaɪəs hæd tə əɡɹi ðət ɡoʊɪŋ ɝaʊn ðoʊz wəd teɪk əm tu fɑɹ aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ weɪ. hi dɪd nɑt lɛɾ əm sɪmpli kɹɔs oʊvɝ, ðoʊ. livɪŋ əm ət ðə beɪs ə ðə sloʊp, hi wəd kɹip ʌp tə ðə kɹɛst ɑn ɪz bɛli, piɹɪŋ oʊvɝ əz kɔʃəsli əz ðoʊ ðə wʊlvz hæd nɑt skaʊɾəd ðəɹ tɛn mɪnəts bɪfɔɹ. weɪɾɪŋ ət ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə ɹɪdʒ, mɪnəts pæs laɪk aʊɝz, ən ðə nɑt noʊɪŋ pɹɛst ɑn ðɛm. ɛɡwin tʃuɾ əɹ lɪp ən ʌnkɑnʃəsli klɪk ðə bidz ɛɹæm hæd ɡɪvən əɹ θɹu hɝ fɪŋɡɝz. pɛɹɪn weɪɾəd dɔɡədli. hɪz stʌmək twɪstəɾ ʌp ɪn ə sɪk nɑt, bʌɾ i mænədʒ tə kip ɪz feɪs kɑm, mænədʒ tə kip ðə tɝmɔɪl hɪɾən ɪnsaɪd.

Sometimes a longer ridge than usual lay across their path, stretching miles and miles to east and west. Even Elyas had to agree that going around those would take them too far out of their way. He did not let them simply cross over, though. Leaving them at the base of the slope, he would creep up to the crest on his belly, peering over as cautiously as though the wolves had not scouted there ten minutes before. Waiting at the bottom of the ridge, minutes passed like hours, and the not knowing pressed on them. Egwene chewed her lip and unconsciously clicked the beads Aram had given her through her fingers. Perrin waited doggedly. His stomach twisted up in a sick knot, but he managed to keep his face calm, managed to keep the turmoil hidden inside.

ðə wʊlvz wɪl wɔɹn ɪf ðɛɹz deɪnʒɝ. ɪt wəd bi wʌndɝfəl ɪf ðeɪ wɛn əweɪ, ɪf ðeɪ dʒʌs vænɪʃt, bʌt ɹaɪt naʊ . . . ɹaɪt naʊ, ðəl ɡɪv wɔɹnɪŋ. wʌɾ ɪz i lʊkɪŋ fɔɹ? wʌt?

The wolves will warn if there's danger. It would be wonderful if they went away, if they just vanished, but right now . . . right now, they'll give warning. What is he looking for? What?

æftɝ ə lɔŋ sɝtʃ wɪð oʊnli hɪz aɪz əbʌv ðə ɹaɪz, ɛlaɪəs ɔlweɪz moʊʃən əm tə kʌm əhɛd. ɛvɹi taɪm ðə weɪ əhɛd wɑz klɪɹ - əntɪl ðə nɛks taɪm ðeɪ faʊn ə ɹɪdʒ ðeɪ kəd nɑt ɡoʊ ɝaʊnd. ət ðə θɝd sətʃ ɹɪdʒ, pɛɹɪnz stʌmək lɝtʃt. saʊɝ fjumz ɹoʊz ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt, ən i nu ɪf i hæd tə weɪɾ ivən faɪv mɪnəts i wəd vɑmət. "aɪ. . . ." hi swɑloʊd. "aɪm kʌmɪŋ, tu."

After a long search with only his eyes above the rise, Elyas always motioned them to come ahead. Every time the way ahead was clear - until the next time they found a ridge they could not go around. At the third such ridge, Perrin's stomach lurched. Sour fumes rose in his throat, and he knew if he had to wait even five minutes he would vomit. "I. . . ." He swallowed. "I'm coming, too."

"kip loʊ," wɑz ɔl ɛlaɪəs sɛd.

"Keep low," was all Elyas said.

əz sun əz i spoʊk ɛɡwin dʒʌmp daʊn fɹəm bɛlə.

As soon as he spoke Egwene jumped down from Bela.

ðə fɝ-klæd mæn pʊʃt ɪz ɹaʊn hæt fɔɹwɝɾ ən pɪɹɾ əɾ əɹ fɹəm ʌndɝ ði ɛdʒ. "ju ɪkspɛktɪŋ tə meɪk ðət mɛɹ kɹɔl?" hi sɛd dʒɹaɪli.

The fur-clad man pushed his round hat forward and peered at her from under the edge. "You expecting to make that mare crawl?" he said dryly.

hɝ maʊθ wɝkt, bʌt noʊ saʊn keɪm aʊt. faɪnəli ʃi ʃɹʌɡd, ən ɛlaɪəs tɝn əweɪ wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝɾ ən bɪɡæn klaɪmɪŋ ði izi sloʊp. pɛɹɪn hɝiɾ æftɝ hɪm.

Her mouth worked, but no sound came out. Finally she shrugged, and Elyas turned away without another word and began climbing the easy slope. Perrin hurried after him.

wɛl ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə kɹɛst ɛlaɪəs meɪɾ ə daʊnwɝd moʊʃən ən ə moʊmən leɪɾɝ flæɾənd hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɹɪəlɪŋ fɔɹwɝd ðə læs fju jɑɹdz. pɛɹɪn flɑpt ɑn ɪz bɛli.

Well short of the crest Elyas made a downward motion and a moment later flattened himself on the ground, wriggling forward the last few yards. Perrin flopped on his belly.

ət ðə tɑp, ɛlaɪəs tʊk ɔf ɪz hæt bɪfɔɹ ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɛvɝ soʊ sloʊli. piɹɪŋ θɹu ə klʌmp ə θɔɹni widz, pɛɹɪn sɔ oʊnli ðə seɪm ɹoʊlɪŋ pleɪn ðət leɪ bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ðə daʊn-sloʊp wɑz bɛɹ, ðoʊ ə klʌmp ə tʃɹiz ə hʌnʒɹəd peɪsɪz əkɹɔs ɡɹu ɪn ðə hɑloʊ, pɝhæps hæf ə maɪl saʊθ fɹəm ðə ɹɪdʒ. ðə wʊlvz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn θɹu ɪt, smɛlɪŋ noʊ tʃɹeɪs ə tʃɹɑləks əɹ mɹdʒɹɑl.

At the top, Elyas took off his hat before raising his head ever so slowly. Peering through a clump of thorny weeds, Perrin saw only the same rolling plain that lay behind them. The down-slope was bare, though a clump of trees a hundred paces across grew in the hollow, perhaps half a mile south from the ridge.
