The wolves had already been through it, smelling no trace of Trollocs or Myrddraal.

ist ən wɛs ðə lænd wɑz ðə seɪm əz fɑɹ əz pɛɹɪn kəd si, ɹoʊlɪŋ ɡɹæslæn ən waɪd-skæɾɝd θɪkəts. nʌθɪŋ muvd. ðə wʊlvz wɝ mɔɹ ðən ə maɪl əhɛd, aʊɾ ə saɪt; ət ðət dɪstəns i kəd bɛɹli fil ðɛm. ðeɪ hæd sin nʌθɪŋ wən ðeɪ kʌvɝd ðɪs ɡɹaʊnd. wʌɾ ɪz i lʊkɪŋ fɔɹ? ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ ðɛɹ.

East and west the land was the same as far as Perrin could see, rolling grassland and wide-scattered thickets. Nothing moved. The wolves were more than a mile ahead, out of sight; at that distance he could barely feel them. They had seen nothing when they covered this ground. What is he looking for? There's nothing there.

"wɝ weɪstɪŋ taɪm," hi sɛd, stɑɹɾɪŋ tə stænd, ən ə flɑk ə ɹeɪvənz bɝst aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz bɪloʊ, fɪfti, ə hʌnʒɹəd blæk bɝdz, spaɪɹəlɪŋ ɪndə ðə skaɪ. hi fɹoʊz ɪn ə kɹaʊtʃ əz ðeɪ mɪld oʊvɝ ðə tʃɹiz. ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪz. dɪd ðeɪ si mi? swɛt tʃɹɪkəl daʊn ɪz feɪs.

"We're wasting time," he said, starting to stand, and a flock of ravens burst out of the trees below, fifty, a hundred black birds, spiraling into the sky. He froze in a crouch as they milled over the trees. The Dark One's Eyes. Did they see me? Sweat trickled down his face.

əz ɪf wʌn θɔt hæd sʌɾənli spɑɹkt ɪn ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪni maɪnz, ɛvɹi ɹeɪvən bɹoʊk ʃɑɹpli ɪn ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən. saʊθ. ðə flɑk dɪsəpɪɹɾ oʊvɝ ðə nɛkst ɹaɪz, ɔlɹɛɾi dɪsɛndɪŋ. tə ði ist ənʌðɝ θɪkɪt dɪsɡɔɹdʒ mɔɹ ɹeɪvənz. ðə blæk mæs wil twaɪs ən hɛɾəd saʊθ.

As if one thought had suddenly sparked in a hundred tiny minds, every raven broke sharply in the same direction. South. The flock disappeared over the next rise, already descending. To the east another thicket disgorged more ravens. The black mass wheeled twice and headed south.

ʃeɪkɪŋ, hi loʊɝd hɪmsɛlf tə ðə ɡɹaʊn sloʊli. hi tʃɹaɪd tə spik, bʌɾ ɪz maʊθ wɑz tu dʒɹaɪ. æftɝ ə mɪnəɾ i mænədʒ tə wɝk ʌp səm spɪt. "wɑz ðət wʌt jə wɝ əfɹeɪɾ ʌv? waɪ dɪdn jə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ? waɪ dɪdn ðə wʊlvz si ðɛm?"

Shaking, he lowered himself to the ground slowly. He tried to speak, but his mouth was too dry. After a minute he managed to work up some spit. "Was that what you were afraid of? Why didn't you say something? Why didn't the wolves see them?"

"wʊlvz doʊn lʊk ʌp ɪn tʃɹiz mʌtʃ," ɛlaɪəs ɡɹaʊld. "ænd noʊ, aɪ wɑzn lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ðɪs. aɪ toʊl ju, aɪ dɪdnt noʊ wʌt. . . ." fɑɹ tə ðə wɛst ə blæk klaʊd ɹoʊz oʊvɝ jɛɾ ənʌðɝ ɡɹoʊv ən wɪŋ saʊθwɝd. ðeɪ wɝ tu fɑɹ ɔf tə meɪk aʊɾ ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl bɝdz. "ɪɾ ɪzən ə bɪɡ hʌnt, θæŋk ðə laɪt. ðeɪ doʊnt noʊ. ivən æftɝ. . . ." hi tɝn tə stɛɹ bæk ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd kʌm.

"Wolves don't look up in trees much," Elyas growled. "And no, I wasn't looking for this. I told you, I didn't know what. . . ." Far to the west a black cloud rose over yet another grove and winged southward. They were too far off to make out individual birds. "It isn't a big hunt, thank the Light. They don't know. Even after. . . ." He turned to stare back the way they had come.

pɛɹɪn swɑloʊd. ivən æftɝ ðə dʒɹim, ɛlaɪəs hæd mɛnt. "nɑt bɪɡ?" hi sɛd. "bæk hoʊm jə woʊn si ðət mɛni ɹeɪvənz ɪn ə hoʊl jɪɹ."

Perrin swallowed. Even after the dream, Elyas had meant. "Not big?" he said. "Back home you won't see that many ravens in a whole year."

ɛlaɪəs ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz aɪv sin swips wɪð ə θaʊzən ɹeɪvənz tə ðə flɑk. nɑt tu ɔfən - ðɛɹz ə baʊnti ɑn ɹeɪvənz ðəɹ - bʌɾ ɪts hæpənd." hi wɑz stɪl lʊkɪŋ nɔɹθ. "hʌʃ, naʊ."

Elyas shook his head. "In the Borderlands I've seen sweeps with a thousand ravens to the flock. Not too often - there's a bounty on ravens there - but it has happened." He was still looking north. "Hush, now."

pɛɹɪn fɛlt ɪt, ðɛn; ði ɛfɝɾ ə ɹitʃɪŋ aʊt tə ðə dɪstənt wʊlvz. ɛlaɪəs wɑntəd dæpəl ən əɹ kəmpænjənz tə kwɪt skaʊɾɪŋ əhɛd, tə hɝi bæk ən tʃɛk ðɛɹ bæktʃɹeɪl. hɪz ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɔn feɪs taɪɾənd ən θɪn ʌndɝ ðə stʃɹeɪn. ðə wʊlvz wɝ soʊ fɑɹ əweɪ pɛɹɪn kəd nɑɾ ivən fil ðɛm. hɝi. wɑtʃ ðə skaɪ. hɝi.

Perrin felt it, then; the effort of reaching out to the distant wolves. Elyas wanted Dapple and her companions to quit scouting ahead, to hurry back and check their backtrail. His already gaunt face tightened and thinned under the strain. The wolves were so far away Perrin could not even feel them. Hurry. Watch the sky. Hurry.

feɪnli pɛɹɪn kɑt ðə ɹɪplaɪ fɹəm fɑɹ tə ðə saʊθ. wi kʌm. ən ɪmədʒ flæʃt ɪn ɪz maɪnd - wʊlvz ɹʌnɪŋ, mʌzəlz pɔɪntɪŋ ɪndə ðə wɪn ə ðɛɹ heɪst, ɹʌnɪŋ əz ɪf waɪldfaɪɝ ɹeɪs bɪhaɪnd, ɹʌnɪŋ - flæʃt ən wɑz ɡɔn ɪn ən ɪnstənt.

Faintly Perrin caught the reply from far to the south. We come. An image flashed in his mind - wolves running, muzzles pointing into the wind of their haste, running as if wildfire raced behind, running - flashed and was gone in an instant.

ɛlaɪəs slʌmpt ən dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ. fɹaʊnɪŋ, hi pɪɹɾ oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪdʒ, ðən bæk tə ðə nɔɹθ, ən mʌɾɝd ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ.

Elyas slumped and drew a deep breath. Frowning, he peered over the ridge, then back to the north, and muttered under his breath.

"ju θɪŋk ðəɹ ɑɹ mɔɹ ɹeɪvənz bɪhaɪn ʌs?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"You think there are more ravens behind us?" Perrin asked.

"kʊd bi," ɛlaɪəs sɛd veɪɡli. "ðeɪ də ɪt ðət weɪ, səmtaɪmz. aɪ noʊ ə pleɪs, ɪf wi kən ɹitʃ ɪt baɪ dɑɹk. wɪv tə kip muvɪŋ əntɪl fʊl dɑɹk ɛniweɪ, ivən ɪf wi doʊnt ɡɛt ðɛɹ, bʌt wi kænt ɡoʊ əz fæst əz aɪ wəd laɪk. kæn əfɔɹd tə ɡɛt tu kloʊs tə ðə ɹeɪvənz əhɛɾ ʌv ʌs. bʌɾ ɪf ðəɹ bɪhaɪn ʌs, tu. . . ."

"Could be," Elyas said vaguely. "They do it that way, sometimes. I know a place, if we can reach it by dark. We have to keep moving until full dark anyway, even if we don't get there, but we can't go as fast as I would like. Can't afford to get too close to the ravens ahead of us. But if they're behind us, too. . . ."

"waɪ dɑɹk?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. "wʌt pleɪs? sʌmwɛɹ seɪf fɹəm ðə ɹeɪvənz?"

"Why dark?" Perrin said. "What place? Somewhere safe from the ravens?"

"seɪf fɹəm ɹeɪvənz," ɛlaɪəs sɛd, "bʌt tu mɛni pipəl noʊ. . . . ɹeɪvənz ɹus fəɹ ðə naɪt. wi doʊn əv tə wɝi əbaʊɾ əm faɪndɪŋ əs ɪn ðə dɑɹk. ðə laɪt sɛn ɹeɪvənz ɑɹ ɔl wɪv tə wɝi əbaʊt ðɛn." wɪð wʌn mɔɹ lʊk oʊvɝ ðə kɹɛst, hi ɹoʊz ən weɪv tə ɛɡwin tə bɹɪŋ bɛlə ʌp. "bʌt dɑɹk ɪz ə lɔŋ weɪ ɔf. wɪv tə ɡɛt muvɪŋ." hi stɑɹɾəd daʊn ðə fɑɹ sloʊp ɪn ə ʃæmbəlɪŋ ɹʌn, itʃ stʃɹaɪd bɛɹli kætʃɪŋ ɪm ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə fɔlɪŋ. "muv, bɝn ju!"

"Safe from ravens," Elyas said, "but too many people know. . . . Ravens roost for the night. We don't have to worry about them finding us in the dark. The Light send ravens are all we have to worry about then." With one more look over the crest, he rose and waved to Egwene to bring Bela up. "But dark is a long way off. We have to get moving." He started down the far slope in a shambling run, each stride barely catching him on the edge of falling. "Move, burn you!"

pɛɹɪn muvd, hæf ɹʌnɪŋ, hæf slaɪɾɪŋ, æftɝ hɪm.

Perrin moved, half running, half sliding, after him.

ɛɡwin tɑp ðə ɹaɪz bɪhaɪn ðɛm, kɪkɪŋ bɛlə tə ə tʃɹɑt. ə ɡɹɪn ə ɹɪlif blumd ɑn əɹ feɪs wən ʃi sɔ ðɛm. "wʌts ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn?" ʃi kɔld, ɝdʒɪŋ ðə ʃæɡi mɛɹ tə kætʃ ʌp. "wɛn jə dɪsəpɪɹd laɪk ðæt, aɪ θɔt. . . . wʌt hæpənd?"

Egwene topped the rise behind them, kicking Bela to a trot. A grin of relief bloomed on her face when she saw them. "What's going on?" she called, urging the shaggy mare to catch up. "When you disappeared like that, I thought. . . . What happened?"

pɛɹɪn seɪvd ɪz bɹɛθ fəɹ ɹʌnɪŋ əntɪl ʃi ɹitʃt ðɛm. hi ɪkspleɪn əbaʊt ðə ɹeɪvənz ən ɛlaɪəsəz seɪf pleɪs, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ə dɪsdʒɔɪntɪd stɔɹi. æftɝ ə stʃɹæŋɡəld, "ɹeɪvənz!" ʃi kɛpt ɪntɝʌptɪŋ wɪð kwɛstʃənz fəɹ wɪtʃ, əz ɔfən əz nɑt, hi hæd noʊ ænsɝz. bɪtwin ðɛm, hi dɪd nɑt fɪnɪʃ əntɪl ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə nɛkst ɹɪdʒ.

Perrin saved his breath for running until she reached them. He explained about the ravens and Elyas's safe place, but it was a disjointed story. After a strangled, "Ravens!" she kept interrupting with questions for which, as often as not, he had no answers. Between them, he did not finish until they reached the next ridge.

ɔɹɾənɛɹəli - ɪf ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə dʒɝni kəd bi kɔld ɔɹɾənɛɹi - ðeɪ wʊɾə ɡɔn ɝaʊn ðɪs wʌn ɹæðɝ ðən oʊvɝ, bʌɾ ɛlaɪəs ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn skaʊɾɪŋ ɛniweɪ.

Ordinarily - if anything about the journey could be called ordinary - they would have gone around this one rather than over, but Elyas insisted on scouting anyway.

"ju wɑnə dʒʌst sɔntɝ ɹaɪɾ ɪndə ðə mɪɾəl ə ðɛm, bɔɪ?" wɑz ɪz saʊɝ kɑmɛnt.

"You want to just saunter right into the middle of them, boy?" was his sour comment.

ɛɡwin stɛɹɾ ət ðə kɹɛst ə ðə ɹɪdʒ, lɪkɪŋ əɹ lɪps, əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ wɪð ɛlaɪəs ðɪs taɪm ən wɑntəd tə steɪ wɛɹ ʃi wɑz, tu. ɛlaɪəs wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn u ʃoʊd noʊ hɛzəteɪʃən.

Egwene stared at the crest of the ridge, licking her lips, as if she wanted to go with Elyas this time and wanted to stay where she was, too. Elyas was the only one who showed no hesitation.

pɛɹɪn wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðə ɹeɪvənz ɛvɝ dʌbəl bæk. ɪt wəd bi ə faɪn θɪŋ tə ɹitʃ ðə kɹɛst ət ðə seɪm taɪm əz ə flɑk ə ɹeɪvənz.

Perrin wondered if the ravens ever doubled back. It would be a fine thing to reach the crest at the same time as a flock of ravens.

ət ðə tɑp i ɪntʃt ɪz hɛɾ ʌp əntɪl i kəd dʒʌst si, ən hivd ə saɪ ʌv ɹɪlif wən ɔl i sɔ wɑz ə kɑps ə tʃɹiz ə lɪɾəl tə ðə wɛst. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɹeɪvənz tə bi sin. əbɹʌpli ə fɑks bɝst aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz, ɹʌnɪŋ hɑɹd. ɹeɪvənz pɔɹd fɹəm ðə bɹæntʃəz æftɝ ɪt. ðə biɾ ə ðɛɹ wɪŋz ɔlmoʊs dʒɹaʊn aʊɾ ə dɛspɹɪt waɪnɪŋ fɹəm ðə fɑks. ə blæk wɝlwɪn dʌv ən swɝld ɝaʊn ɪt. ðə fɑksəz dʒɔz snæpt ət ðɛm, bʌt ðeɪ dɑɹɾɪd ɪn, ən dɑɹɾɪd əweɪ əntʌtʃt, blæk biks ɡlɪsnɪŋ wɛtli. ðə fɑks tɝn bæk təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹiz, sikɪŋ ðə seɪfti ʌv ɪts dɛn. ɪt ɹæn ɔkwɝdli naʊ, hɛd loʊ, fɝ dɑɹk ən blʌɾi, ən ðə ɹeɪvənz flæpt ɝaʊn ɪt, mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ə ðɛm ət wʌns, ðə flʌɾɝɪŋ mæs θɪkənɪŋ əntɪl ɪt hɪd ðə fɑks kəmplitli. əz sʌɾənli əz ðeɪ hæd dɪsɛndəd ðə ɹeɪvənz ɹoʊz, wild, ən vænɪʃt oʊvɝ ðə nɛkst ɹaɪz tə ðə saʊθ. ə mɪsʃeɪpən lʌmp ə tɔɹn fɝ mɑɹkt wʌt hæd bɪn ðə fɑks.

At the top he inched his head up until he could just see, and heaved a sigh of relief when all he saw was a copse of trees a little to the west. There were no ravens to be seen. Abruptly a fox burst out of the trees, running hard. Ravens poured from the branches after it. The beat of their wings almost drowned out a desperate whining from the fox. A black whirlwind dove and swirled around it. The fox's jaws snapped at them, but they darted in, and darted away untouched, black beaks glistening wetly. The fox turned back toward the trees, seeking the safety of its den. It ran awkwardly now, head low, fur dark and bloody, and the ravens flapped around it, more and more of them at once, the fluttering mass thickening until it hid the fox completely. As suddenly as they had descended the ravens rose, wheeled, and vanished over the next rise to the south. A misshapen lump of torn fur marked what had been the fox.

pɛɹɪn swɑloʊd hɑɹd. laɪt! ðeɪ kəd də ðət tə ʌs. ə hʌnʒɹəd ɹeɪvənz. ðeɪ kəd -  "muv," ɛlaɪəs ɡɹaʊld, dʒʌmpɪŋ ʌp. hi weɪv tə ɛɡwin tə kʌm ɑn, ən wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ sɛɾ ɔf əɾ ə tʃɹɑt təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹiz. "muv, bɝn ju!" hi kɔld oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "muv!"

Perrin swallowed hard. Light! They could do that to us. A hundred ravens. They could -  "Move," Elyas growled, jumping up. He waved to Egwene to come on, and without waiting set off at a trot toward the trees. "Move, burn you!" he called over his shoulder. "Move!"

ɛɡwin ɡæləp bɛlə oʊvɝ ðə ɹaɪz ən kɑɾ əm bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə bɑɾəm ə ðə sloʊp. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɛkspləneɪʃənz, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz pɪkt aʊt ðə fɑks ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. hɝ feɪs wɛn əz waɪɾ əz snoʊ.

Egwene galloped Bela over the rise and caught them before they reached the bottom of the slope. There was no time for explanations, but her eyes picked out the fox right away. Her face went as white as snow.

ɛlaɪəs ɹitʃt ðə tʃɹiz ən tɝn ðɛɹ, ət ði ɛdʒ ə ðə kɑps, weɪvɪŋ vɪɡɝəsli fəɹ əm tə hɝi. pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd tə ɹʌn fæstɝ ən stʌmbəld. ɑɹmz wɪndmɪlɪŋ, hi bɛɹli kɑt hɪmsɛlf ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ flæɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs. blʌɾ ən æʃəz! aɪm ɹʌnɪŋ əz fæst əz aɪ kæn!

Elyas reached the trees and turned there, at the edge of the copse, waving vigorously for them to hurry. Perrin tried to run faster and stumbled. Arms windmilling, he barely caught himself short of going flat on his face. Blood and ashes! I'm running as fast as I can!

ə loʊn ɹeɪvən wɪŋd aʊɾ ə ðə kɑps. ɪt tɪltəd təwɔɹd ðɛm, skɹimd, ən spʌn təwɔɹd ðə saʊθ. noʊɪŋ i wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi tu leɪt, pɛɹɪn fʌmbəld ɪz slɪŋ fɹəm ɝaʊn ɪz weɪst. hi wɑz stɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ə stoʊn fɹəm ɪz pɑkət tə ðə slɪŋ wən ðə ɹeɪvən əbɹʌpli foʊldəɾ ʌp ɪn mɪd-ɛɹ ən plʌməɾɪd tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hɪz maʊθ dʒɹɑpt oʊpən, ən ðən i sɔ ðə slɪŋ hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ɛɡwinz hænd. ʃi ɡɹɪn əɾ ɪm ənstɛɾəli.

A lone raven winged out of the copse. It tilted toward them, screamed, and spun toward the south. Knowing he was already too late, Perrin fumbled his sling from around his waist. He was still trying to get a stone from his pocket to the sling when the raven abruptly folded up in mid-air and plummeted to the ground. His mouth dropped open, and then he saw the sling hanging from Egwene's hand. She grinned at him unsteadily.

"doʊn stæn ðəɹ kaʊntɪŋ jəɹ toʊz!" ɛlaɪəs kɔld.

"Don't stand there counting your toes!" Elyas called.

wɪð ə stɑɹt pɛɹɪn hɝiɾ ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz, ðən dʒʌmpt aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ tə əvɔɪd biɪŋ tʃɹæmpəl baɪ ɛɡwin ən bɛlə.

With a start Perrin hurried into the trees, then jumped out of the way to avoid being trampled by Egwene and Bela.

fɑɹ tə ðə wɛst, ɔlmoʊst aʊɾ ə saɪt, wʌt sim laɪk ə dɑɹk mɪst ɹoʊz ɪndə ði ɛɹ. pɛɹɪn fɛl ðə wʊlvz pæsɪŋ ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən, hɛɾɪŋ nɔɹθ. hi fɛlt əm noʊɾəs ɹeɪvənz, tə ðə lɛft ən ɹaɪɾ ə ðɛm, wɪθaʊt sloʊɪŋ. ðə dɑɹk mɪst swɝl nɔɹθwɝɾ əz ɪf pɝsuɪŋ ðə wʊlvz, ðən əbɹʌpli bɹoʊk ɔf ən flæʃt tə ðə saʊθ.

Far to the west, almost out of sight, what seemed like a dark mist rose into the air. Perrin felt the wolves passing in that direction, heading north. He felt them notice ravens, to the left and right of them, without slowing. The dark mist swirled northward as if pursuing the wolves, then abruptly broke off and flashed to the south.

"du jə θɪŋk ðeɪ sɔ ʌs?" ɛɡwin æskt. "wi wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ðə tʃɹiz, wɝnt wi? ðeɪ kʊdn si əs ət ðət dɪstəns. kəd ðeɪ? nɑt ðət fɑɹ ɔf."

"Do you think they saw us?" Egwene asked. "We were already in the trees, weren't we? They couldn't see us at that distance. Could they? Not that far off."

"wi sɔ ðɛm ət ðət dɪstəns," ɛlaɪəs sɛd dʒɹaɪli. pɛɹɪn ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli, ən ɛɡwin dʒɹu ə fɹaɪɾənd bɹɛθ. "ɪf ðeɪ hæd sin ʌs," ɛlaɪəs ɡɹaʊld, "ðeɪɾ əv bɪn daʊn ɑn əs laɪk ðeɪ wɝ ɑn ðət fɑks. θɪŋk, ɪf jə wɑnə steɪ əlaɪv. fɪɹ wɪl kɪl jə ɪf jə doʊn kəntʃɹoʊl ɪt." hɪz pɛnətʃɹeɪɾɪŋ stɛɹ hɛld ɑn itʃ ə ðɛm fəɹ ə moʊmənt. faɪnəli hi nɑɾəd. "ðeɪɹ ɡɔn, naʊ, ən wi ʃəd bi, tu. kip ðoʊz slɪŋz hændi. maɪt bi jusfəl əɡɛn."

"We saw them at that distance," Elyas said dryly. Perrin shifted uneasily, and Egwene drew a frightened breath. "If they had seen us," Elyas growled, "they'd have been down on us like they were on that fox. Think, if you want to stay alive. Fear will kill you if you don't control it." His penetrating stare held on each of them for a moment. Finally he nodded. "They're gone, now, and we should be, too. Keep those slings handy. Might be useful again."

əz ðeɪ muvd aʊɾ ə ðə kɑps, ɛlaɪəs æŋɡəld əm wɛstwɝd fɹəm ðə laɪn ə mɑɹtʃ ðeɪ hæd bɪn fɑloʊɪŋ. pɛɹɪnz bɹɛθ snæɡd ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt; ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ tʃeɪsɪŋ æftɝ ðə læst ɹeɪvənz ðeɪ hæd sin. ɛlaɪəs kɛpt ɑn taɪɹləsli, ən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ fəɹ əm tə də bʌt fɑloʊ. æftɝ ɔl, ɛlaɪəs nu ə seɪf pleɪs. sʌmwɛɹ. soʊ hi sɛd.

As they moved out of the copse, Elyas angled them westward from the line of march they had been following. Perrin's breath snagged in his throat; it was as if they were chasing after the last ravens they had seen. Elyas kept on tirelessly, and there was nothing for them to do but follow. After all, Elyas knew a safe place. Somewhere. So he said.

ðeɪ ɹæn tə ðə nɛks hɪl, weɪɾəd tɪl ðə ɹeɪvənz muvd ɑn, ðən ɹæn əɡɛn, weɪɾəd, ɹæn. ðə stɛɾi pɹɑɡɹɛs ðeɪ hæd bɪn kipɪŋ hæd bɪn taɪɹɪŋ ɪnʌf, bʌɾ ɔl ɪksɛpt ɛlaɪəs kwɪkli bɪɡæn tə flæɡ ʌndɝ ðɪs dʒɝki peɪs. pɛɹɪnz tʃɛs hivd, ən i ɡʌlpt ɛɹ wən i hæɾ ə fju mɪnəts tə laɪ ɑn ə hɪltɑp, livɪŋ ðə sɝtʃ tə ɛlaɪəs. bɛlə stʊd hɛd daʊn, nɑstʃɹəlz flɛɹɪŋ, əɾ ɛvɹi stɑp. fɪɹ læʃt əm ɑn, ən pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪf ɪt wɑz kəntʃɹoʊld əɹ nɑt. hi oʊnli wɪʃt ðə wʊlvz wəd tɛl əm wʌt wɑz bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ɪf ɛniθɪŋ wɑz, wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz.

They ran to the next hill, waited till the ravens moved on, then ran again, waited, ran. The steady progress they had been keeping had been tiring enough, but all except Elyas quickly began to flag under this jerky pace. Perrin's chest heaved, and he gulped air when he had a few minutes to lie on a hilltop, leaving the search to Elyas. Bela stood head down, nostrils flaring, at every stop. Fear lashed them on, and Perrin did not know if it was controlled or not. He only wished the wolves would tell them what was behind them, if anything was, Whatever it was.

əhɛd wɝ mɔɹ ɹeɪvənz ðən pɛɹɪn ɛvɝ hoʊp tə si əɡɛn. tə ðə lɛft ən ɹaɪt ðə blæk bɝdz bɪloʊɾ ʌp, ən tə ðə saʊθ. ə dʌzən taɪmz ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs ʌv ə ɡɹoʊv əɹ ðə skænt ʃɛltɝ ʌv ə sloʊp oʊnli moʊməns bɪfɔɹ ɹeɪvənz swɛpt ɪndə ðə skaɪ. wʌns, wɪð ðə sʌn bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə slaɪd fɹəm ɪts mɪddeɪ haɪt, ðeɪ stʊɾ ɪn ði oʊpən, fɹoʊzən əz stɪl əz stætʃuz, hæf ə maɪl fɹəm ðə nɪɹəs kʌvɝ, waɪl ə hʌnʒɹəd ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz fɛðɝd spaɪz flæʃt baɪ ə bɛɹ maɪl tə ði ist. swɛt ɹoʊl daʊn pɛɹɪnz feɪs dɪspaɪt ðə wɪnd, əntɪl ðə læs blæk ʃeɪp dwɪndəl tə ə dɑɾ ən vænɪʃt. hi lɔs kaʊn ə ðə stʃɹæɡlɝz ðeɪ bɹɔt daʊn wɪð ðɛɹ slɪŋz.

Ahead were more ravens than Perrin ever hoped to see again. To the left and right the black birds billowed up, and to the south. A dozen times they reached the hiding place of a grove or the scant shelter of a slope only moments before ravens swept into the sky. Once, with the sun beginning to slide from its midday height, they stood in the open, frozen as still as statues, half a mile from the nearest cover, while a hundred of the Dark One's feathered spies flashed by a bare mile to the east. Sweat rolled down Perrin's face despite the wind, until the last black shape dwindled to a dot and vanished. He lost count of the stragglers they brought down with their slings.

hi sɔ mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf ɛvəɾəns laɪɪŋ ɪn ðə pæθ ðə ɹeɪvənz hæd kʌvɝd tə dʒʌstəfaɪ hɪz fɪɹ. hi hæd stɛɹd wɪð ə kwizi fæsəneɪʃən əɾ ə ɹæbət ðət hæd bɪn tɔɹn tə pisəz. ði aɪləs hɛd stʊɾ əpɹaɪt, wɪð ði ʌðɝ bɪts - lɛɡz, ɛntʃɹəlz - skæɾɝd ɪn ə ɹʌf sɝkəl ɝaʊn ɪt. bɝdz, tu, stæb tə ʃeɪpləs mæsəz ə fɛðɝz. ən tu mɔɹ fɑksəz.

He saw more than enough evidence lying in the path the ravens had covered to justify his fear. He had stared with a queasy fascination at a rabbit that had been torn to pieces. The eyeless head stood upright, with the other bits - legs, entrails - scattered in a rough circle around it. Birds, too, stabbed to shapeless masses of feathers. And two more foxes.

hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd sʌmθɪŋ læn hæd sɛd. ɔl ðə dɑɹk wʌnz kɹitʃɝz dɪlaɪɾ ɪn kɪlɪŋ. ðə dɑɹk wʌnz paʊɝ ɪz dɛθ. ən ɪf ðə ɹeɪvənz faʊn ðɛm? pɪɾiləs aɪz ʃaɪnɪŋ laɪk blæk bidz. stæbɪŋ biks swɝlɪŋ ɝaʊn ðɛm. niɾəl-ʃɑɹp biks dʒɹɔɪŋ blʌd. ə hʌnʒɹəd ə ðɛm. əɹ kən ðeɪ kɔl mɔɹ ə ðɛɹ kaɪnd? meɪbi ɔl ə ðɛm ɪn ðə hʌnt? ə sɪkənɪŋ ɪmədʒ bɪlt ʌp ɪn ɪz maɪnd. ə paɪl ə ɹeɪvənz əz bɪɡ əz ə hɪl, siθɪŋ laɪk mæɡəts, faɪɾɪŋ oʊvɝ ə fju blʌɾi ʃɹɛdz.

He remembered something Lan had said. All the Dark One's creatures delight in killing. The Dark One's power is death. And if the ravens found them? Pitiless eyes shining like black beads. Stabbing beaks swirling around them. Needle-sharp beaks drawing blood. A hundred of them. Or can they call more of their kind? Maybe all of them in the hunt? A sickening image built up in his mind. A pile of ravens as big as a hill, seething like maggots, fighting over a few bloody shreds.

sʌɾənli ði ɪmədʒ wɑz swɛpt əweɪ baɪ ʌðɝz, itʃ wʌn klɪɹ fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ðən spɪnɪŋ ən feɪɾɪŋ ɪndə ənʌðɝ. ðə wʊlvz hæd faʊn ɹeɪvənz tə ðə nɔɹθ. skɹimɪŋ bɝdz dʌv ən wɝld ən dʌv əɡɛn, biks dʒɹɔɪŋ blʌd wɪð ɛvɹi swup. snɑɹlɪŋ wʊlvz dɑdʒd ən lɛpt, twɪstɪŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, dʒɔz snæpɪŋ. əɡɛn ən əɡɛn pɛɹɪn teɪstəd fɛðɝz ən ðə faʊl teɪst ə flʌɾɝɪŋ ɹeɪvənz kɹʌʃt əlaɪv, fɛl ðə peɪn ʌv uzɪŋ ɡæʃəz ɔl oʊvɝ ɪz bɑɾi, nu wɪð ə dɪspɛɹ ðət nɛvɝ tʌtʃt ɑn ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp ðəɾ ɔl ɪz ɛfɝt wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf. sʌɾənli ðə ɹeɪvənz bɹoʊk əweɪ, wilɪŋ oʊvɝhɛd fəɹ wʌn læst ʃɹik ə ɹeɪdʒ ət ðə wʊlvz. wʊlvz dɪd nɑt daɪ əz izəli əz fɑksəz, ən ðeɪ hæɾ ə mɪʃən. ə flæp ə blæk wɪŋz, ən ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn, ə fju blæk fɛðɝz dʒɹɪftɪŋ daʊn ɑn ðɛɹ dɛd. wɪn lɪkt əɾ ə pʌŋktʃɝ ɑn ɪz lɛft fɔɹɛlɪɡ. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ wɪð wʌn ə hɑpɝz aɪz. ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ əɹ oʊn hɝts, dæpəl ɡæðɝɾ əm ən ðeɪ sɛɾəld ɪndə ə peɪnfəl loʊp ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ðə ɹeɪvənz hæd ɡɔn. blʌd mæɾɪd ðɛɹ fɝ. wi kʌm. deɪnʒɝ kʌmz bɪfɔɹ ʌs.

Suddenly the image was swept away by others, each one clear for an instant, then spinning and fading into another. The wolves had found ravens to the north. Screaming birds dove and whirled and dove again, beaks drawing blood with every swoop. Snarling wolves dodged and leaped, twisting in the air, jaws snapping. Again and again Perrin tasted feathers and the foul taste of fluttering ravens crushed alive, felt the pain of oozing gashes all over his body, knew with a despair that never touched on giving up that all his effort was not enough. Suddenly the ravens broke away, wheeling overhead for one last shriek of rage at the wolves. Wolves did not die as easily as foxes, and they had a mission. A flap of black wings, and they were gone, a few black feathers drifting down on their dead. Wind licked at a puncture on his left foreleg. There was something wrong with one of Hopper's eyes. Ignoring her own hurts, Dapple gathered them and they settled into a painful lope in the direction the ravens had gone. Blood matted their fur. We come. Danger comes before us.

muvɪŋ ɪn ə stʌmbəlɪŋ tʃɹɑt, pɛɹɪn ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə ɡlæns wɪð ɛlaɪəs. ðə mænz jɛloʊ aɪz wɝ ɪkspɹɛʃənləs, bʌɾ i nu. hi sɛd nʌθɪŋ, dʒʌst wɑtʃt pɛɹɪn ən weɪɾəd, ɔl ðə waɪl meɪnteɪnɪŋ ðəɾ ɛfɝtləs loʊp.

Moving in a stumbling trot, Perrin exchanged a glance with Elyas. The man's yellow eyes were expressionless, but he knew. He said nothing, just watched Perrin and waited, all the while maintaining that effortless lope.

weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ mi. weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ mi tə ədmɪɾ aɪ fil ðə wʊlvz.

Waiting for me. Waiting for me to admit I feel the wolves.

"ɹeɪvənz," pɛɹɪn pæntɪd ɹɪlʌktənli. "bɪhaɪn ʌs."

"Ravens," Perrin panted reluctantly. "Behind us."

"hi wɑz ɹaɪt," ɛɡwin bɹiðd. "ju kən tɔk tə ðɛm."

"He was right," Egwene breathed. "You can talk to them."

pɛɹɪnz fit fɛlt laɪk lʌmps ʌv aɪɝn ɑn ði ɛnz ʌv wʊɾən poʊsts, bʌɾ i tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk əm muv fæstɝ. ɪf i kəɾ aʊtʃɹʌn ðɛɹ aɪz, aʊtʃɹʌn ðə ɹeɪvənz, aʊtʃɹʌn ðə wʊlvz, bʌɾ əbʌv ɔl ɛɡwinz aɪz, ðət nu hɪm naʊ fəɹ wʌɾ i wɑz. wʌɾ ɑɹ ju? teɪntɪd, ðə laɪt blaɪn mi! kɝst!

Perrin's feet felt like lumps of iron on the ends of wooden posts, but he tried to make them move faster. If he could outrun their eyes, outrun the ravens, outrun the wolves, but above all Egwene's eyes, that knew him now for what he was. What are you? Tainted, the Light blind me! Cursed!

hɪz θɹoʊt bɝn əz ɪt nɛvɝ hæd fɹəm bɹiðɪŋ ðə smoʊk ən hiɾ ə mæstɝ luhənz fɔɹdʒ. hi stæɡɝɾ ən hʌŋ ɑn tə ɛɡwinz stɝəp əntɪl ʃi klaɪm daʊn ən ɔl bʌt pʊʃt ɪm ɪndə ðə sæɾəl dɪspaɪɾ ɪz pɹoʊɾɛsts ðəɾ i kəd kip ɡoʊɪŋ. ɪt wɑz nɑt lɔŋ, ðoʊ, bɪfɔɹ ʃi wɑz klʌtʃɪŋ ðə stɝəp əz ʃi ɹæn, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp əɹ skɝts wɪð əɹ ʌðɝ hænd, ən oʊnli ə lɪɾəl waɪl æftɝ ðəɾ əntɪl i dɪsmaʊntɪd, hɪz niz stɪl wɑbəlɪŋ. hi hæd tə pɪk əɹ ʌp tə meɪk əɹ teɪk ɪz pleɪs, bʌt ʃi wɑz tu taɪɝd tə faɪt hɪm.

His throat burned as it never had from breathing the smoke and heat of Master Luhhan's forge. He staggered and hung on to Egwene's stirrup until she climbed down and all but pushed him into the saddle despite his protests that he could keep going. It was not long, though, before she was clutching the stirrup as she ran, holding up her skirts with her other hand, and only a little while after that until he dismounted, his knees still wobbling. He had to pick her up to make her take his place, but she was too tired to fight him.

ɛlaɪəs wəd nɑt sloʊ daʊn. hi ɝdʒ ðɛm, ən tɔntɪd ðɛm, ən kɛpt əm soʊ kloʊs bɪhaɪn ðə sɝtʃɪŋ ɹeɪvənz tə ðə saʊθ ðət pɛɹɪn θɔɾ ɔl ɪt wəd teɪk wəd bi fəɹ wʌn bɝd tə lʊk bæk. "kip muvɪŋ, bɝn ju! θɪŋk jəl də ɛni bɛɾɝ ðən ðət fɑks dɪd, ɪf ðeɪ kætʃ ʌs? ðə wʌn wɪð ɪts ɪnsaɪdz paɪld ɑn ɪts hɛd?" ɛɡwin sweɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl ən vɑməɾəd nɔɪzəli. "aɪ nu jud ɹɪmɛmbɝ. dʒʌs kip ɡoʊɪŋ ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ. ðæts ɔl. dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl mɔɹ. bɝn ju, aɪ θɔt fɑɹm jʌŋstɝz hæɾ ɛndɝəns. wɝk ɔl deɪ ən dæns ɔl naɪt. slip ɔl deɪ ən slip ɔl naɪt, lʊks laɪk tə mi. muv jəɹ blʌɾi fit!"

Elyas would not slow down. He urged them, and taunted them, and kept them so close behind the searching ravens to the south that Perrin thought all it would take would be for one bird to look back. "Keep moving, burn you! Think you'll do any better than that fox did, if they catch us? The one with its insides piled on its head?" Egwene swayed out of the saddle and vomited noisily. "I knew you'd remember. Just keep going a little more. That's all. Just a little more. Burn you, I thought farm youngsters had endurance. Work all day and dance all night. Sleep all day and sleep all night, looks like to me. Move your bloody feet!"

ðeɪ bɪɡæn kʌmɪŋ daʊn ɔf ðə hɪlz əz sun əz ðə læst ɹeɪvən vænɪʃt oʊvɝ ðə nɛkst wʌn, ðən waɪl ðə læs tʃɹeɪlɝz stɪl flæpt əbʌv ðə hɪltɑp. wʌn bɝd lʊkɪŋ bæk. tə ist ən wɛs ðə ɹeɪvənz sɝtʃt waɪl ðeɪ hɝiɾ əkɹɔs ði oʊpən speɪsəz bɪtwin. wʌn bɝɾ ɪz ɔl ɪɾəl teɪk.

They began coming down off the hills as soon as the last raven vanished over the next one, then while the last trailers still flapped above the hilltop. One bird looking back. To east and west the ravens searched while they hurried across the open spaces between. One bird is all it will take.

ðə ɹeɪvənz bɪhaɪnd wɝ kʌmɪŋ fæst. dæpəl ən ði ʌðɝ wʊlvz wɝk ðɛɹ weɪ ɝaʊn əm ən wɝ kʌmɪŋ ɑn wɪθaʊt stɑpɪŋ tə lɪk ðɛɹ wunz, bʌt ðeɪ hæd lɝn ɔl ðə lɛsənz ðeɪ niɾəd əbaʊt wɑtʃɪŋ ðə skaɪ. haʊ kloʊs? haʊ lɔŋ? ðə wʊlvz hæd noʊ noʊʃənz ə taɪm ðə weɪ mɛn dɪd, noʊ ɹizənz tə dɪvaɪɾ ə deɪ ɪndə aʊɝz. ðə sizənz wɝ taɪm ɪnʌf fəɹ ðɛm, ən ðə laɪɾ ən ðə dɑɹk. noʊ nid fəɹ mɔɹ. faɪnəli pɛɹɪn wɝkt aʊɾ ən ɪmədʒ ʌv wɛɹ ðə sʌn wəd stæn ɪn ðə skaɪ wən ðə ɹeɪvənz oʊvɝɹæn əm fɹəm bɪhaɪnd. hi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət ðə sɛɾɪŋ sʌn, ən lɪkt ɪz lɪps wɪð ə dʒɹaɪ tʌŋ. ɪn ən aʊɝ ðə ɹeɪvənz wəd bi ɑn ðɛm, meɪbi lɛs. ən aʊɝ, ən ɪt wɑz ə ɡʊd tu aʊɝz tə sʌnsɛt, ət lis tu tə fʊl dɑɹk.

The ravens behind were coming fast. Dapple and the other wolves worked their way around them and were coming on without stopping to lick their wounds, but they had learned all the lessons they needed about watching the sky. How close? How long? The wolves had no notions of time the way men did, no reasons to divide a day into hours. The seasons were time enough for them, and the light and the dark. No need for more. Finally Perrin worked out an image of where the sun would stand in the sky when the ravens overran them from behind. He glanced over his shoulder at the setting sun, and licked his lips with a dry tongue. In an hour the ravens would be on them, maybe less. An hour, and it was a good two hours to sunset, at least two to full dark.

wɪl daɪ wɪð ðə sɛɾɪŋ sʌn, hi θɔt, stæɡɝɪŋ əz i ɹæn. slɔɾɝd laɪk ðə fɑks. hi fɪŋɡɝɾ ɪz æks, ðən muv tə hɪz slɪŋ. ðət wəd bi mɔɹ juz. nɑɾ ɪnʌf, ðoʊ. nɑɾ əɡɛnst ə hʌnʒɹəd ɹeɪvənz, ə hʌnʒɹəd dɑɹɾɪŋ tɑɹɡəts, ə hʌnʒɹəd stæbɪŋ biks.

We'll die with the setting sun, he thought, staggering as he ran. Slaughtered like the fox. He fingered his axe, then moved to his sling. That would be more use. Not enough, though. Not against a hundred ravens, a hundred darting targets, a hundred stabbing beaks.

"ɪts jəɹ tɝn tə ɹaɪd, pɛɹɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd taɪɹədli.

"It's your turn to ride, Perrin," Egwene said tiredly.

"ɪn ə bɪt," hi pæntɪd. "aɪm ɡʊd fəɹ maɪlz, jɛt." ʃi nɑɾəd, ən steɪɾ ɪn ðə sæɾəl. ʃiz taɪɝd. tɛl hɝ? əɹ lɛɾ əɹ θɪŋk wi stɪl əv ə tʃæns tə ɪskeɪp? ən aʊɝ ə hoʊp, ivən ɪf ɪts dɛspɹɪt, əɹ ən aʊɝ ə dɪspɛɹ?

"In a bit," he panted. "I'm good for miles, yet." She nodded, and stayed in the saddle. She is tired. Tell her? Or let her think we still have a chance to escape? An hour of hope, even if it is desperate, or an hour of despair?

ɛlaɪəs wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm əɡɛn, seɪɪŋ nʌθɪŋ. hi mʌs noʊ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt spik. pɛɹɪn lʊkt əɾ ɛɡwin əɡɛn ən blɪŋkt əweɪ hɑt tɪɹz. hi tʌtʃt ɪz æks ən wʌndɝɾ ɪf i hæd ðə kɝədʒ. ɪn ðə læs mɪnəts, wən ðə ɹeɪvənz dɪsɛndəɾ ɑn ðɛm, wən ɔl hoʊp wɑz ɡɔn, wəɾ i hæv ðə kɝədʒ tə spɛɹ əɹ ðə dɛθ ðə fɑks hæd daɪd? laɪt meɪk mi stʃɹɔŋ!

Elyas was watching him again, saying nothing. He must know, but he did not speak. Perrin looked at Egwene again and blinked away hot tears. He touched his axe and wondered if he had the courage. In the last minutes, when the ravens descended on them, when all hope was gone, would he have the courage to spare her the death the fox had died? Light make me strong!

ðə ɹeɪvənz əhɛɾ ə ðɛm sʌɾənli sim tə vænɪʃ. pɛɹɪn kəd stɪl meɪk aʊt dɑɹk, mɪsti klaʊdz, fɑɹ tə ði ist ən wɛst, bʌɾ əhɛd . . . nʌθɪŋ. wɛɹ dɪd ðeɪ ɡoʊ? laɪt, ɪf wiv oʊvɝɹʌn ðɛm. . . .

The ravens ahead of them suddenly seemed to vanish. Perrin could still make out dark, misty clouds, far to the east and west, but ahead . . . nothing. Where did they go? Light, if we've overrun them. . . .

əbɹʌpli ə tʃɪl ɹæn θɹu hɪm, wʌn koʊld, klin tɪŋɡəl əz ɪf i hæd dʒʌmpt ɪndə ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ wɔɾɝ ɪn mɪdwɪntɝ. ɪt ɹɪpəl θɹu hɪm ən sim tə kæɹi əweɪ səm ə hɪz fətiɡ, ə lɪɾəl ə ði eɪk ɪn ɪz lɛɡz ən ðə bɝnɪŋ ə hɪz lʌŋz. ɪt lɛf bɪhaɪnd . . . sʌmθɪŋ. hi kəd nɑt seɪ wʌt, oʊnli hi fɛl dɪfɹənt. hi stʌmbəl tə ə hɔlt ən lʊkt ɝaʊnd, əfɹeɪd.

Abruptly a chill ran through him, one cold, clean tingle as if he had jumped into the Winespring Water in midwinter. It rippled through him and seemed to carry away some of his fatigue, a little of the ache in his legs and the burning of his lungs. It left behind . . . something. He could not say what, only he felt different. He stumbled to a halt and looked around, afraid.

ɛlaɪəs wɑtʃt hɪm, wɑtʃt əm ɔl, wɪð ə ɡlim bɪhaɪn ɪz aɪz. hi nu wʌɾ ɪt wɑz, pɛɹɪn wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt, bʌɾ i oʊnli wɑtʃt ðɛm.

Elyas watched him, watched them all, with a gleam behind his eyes. He knew what it was, Perrin was sure of it, but he only watched them.

ɛɡwin ɹeɪn ɪn bɛlə ən lʊkt ɝaʊn ənsɝteɪnli, hæf wʌndɝɪŋ ən hæf fɪɹfəl. "ɪts . . . stʃɹeɪnʒ," ʃi wɪspɝd. "aɪ fil əz ɪf aɪ lɔst sʌmθɪŋ." ivən ðə mɛɹ hæɾ əɹ hɛɾ ʌp ɪkspɛktənli, nɑstʃɹəlz flɛɹɪŋ əz ɪf ðeɪ dɪtɛktəɾ ə feɪn oʊɾɝ ə nu-moʊn heɪ.

Egwene reined in Bela and looked around uncertainly, half wondering and half fearful. "It's . . . strange," she whispered. "I feel as if I lost something." Even the mare had her head up expectantly, nostrils flaring as if they detected a faint odor of new-mown hay.

"wʌt . . . wʌt wɑz ðæt?" pɛɹɪn æskt.

"What . . . what was that?" Perrin asked.

ɛlaɪəs kækəl sʌɾənli. hi bɛn oʊvɝ, ʃoʊldɝz ʃeɪkɪŋ, tə ɹɛst ɪz hænz ɑn ɪz niz. "seɪfti, ðæts wʌt. wi meɪɾ ɪt, jə blʌɾi fulz. noʊ ɹeɪvən wɪl kɹɔs ðət laɪn . . . nɑt wʌn ðət kæɹiz ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪz, ɛniweɪz. eɪ tʃɹɑlɑk wəɾ əv tə bi dʒɹɪvən əkɹɔs, ən ðɛɹəd nid tə bi sʌmθɪŋ fɪɹs pʊʃɪŋ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl tə meɪk ɪm də ðə dʒɹaɪvɪŋ. noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ, iðɝ. ðə wʌn paʊɝ woʊnt wɝk hɪɹ; ðeɪ kæn tʌtʃ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. kæn ivən fil ðə sɔɹs, laɪk ɪt vænɪʃt. meɪks əm ɪtʃ ɪnsaɪd, ðət dʌz. ɡɪvz əm ðə ʃeɪks laɪk ə sɛvən-deɪ dʒɹʌŋk. ɪts seɪfti."

Elyas cackled suddenly. He bent over, shoulders shaking, to rest his hands on his knees. "Safety, that's what. We made it, you bloody fools. No raven will cross that line . . . not one that carries the Dark One's eyes, anyways. A Trolloc would have to be driven across, and there'd need to be something fierce pushing the Myrddraal to make him do the driving. No Aes Sedai, either. The One Power won't work here; they can't touch the True Source. Can't even feel the Source, like it vanished. Makes them itch inside, that does. Gives them the shakes like a seven-day drunk. It's safety."

ət fɝst, tə pɛɹɪnz aɪz, ðə lænd wɑz əntʃeɪnʒd fɹəm ðə ɹoʊlɪŋ hɪlz ən ɹɪdʒəz ðeɪ hæd kɹɔs ðə hoʊl deɪ. ðən i noʊɾəst ɡɹin ʃuts əmʌŋ ðə ɡɹæs; nɑt mɛni, ən ðeɪ wɝ stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ, bʌt mɔɹ ðən i hæd sin ɛniwɛɹ ɛls. ðəɹ wɝ fjuɝ widz ɪn ðə ɡɹæs, tu. hi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən wʌɾ ɪt wɑz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz . . . sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðɪs pleɪs. ən sʌmθɪŋ ɪn wʌɾ ɛlaɪəs sɛd tɪkəld ɪz mɛmɹi.

At first, to Perrin's eyes, the land was unchanged from the rolling hills and ridges they had crossed the whole day. Then he noticed green shoots among the grass; not many, and they were struggling, but more than he had seen anywhere else. There were fewer weeds in the grass, too. He could not imagine what it was, but there was . . . something about this place. And something in what Elyas said tickled his memory.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" ɛɡwin æskt. "aɪ fil. . . . wʌɾ ɪz ðɪs pleɪs? aɪ doʊn θɪŋk aɪ laɪk ɪt."

"What is it?" Egwene asked. "I feel. . . . What is this place? I don't think I like it."

"ə stɛɾɪŋ," ɛlaɪəs ɹɔɹd. "ju nɛvɝ lɪsən tə stɔɹiz? ʌv kɔɹs, ðəɹ hæzən bɪn ən oʊɡiɝ hɪɹ ɪn θɹi θaʊzən ɑd jɪɹz, nɑt sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, bʌɾ ɪts ðə stɛɾɪŋ meɪks ði oʊɡiɝ, nɑt ði oʊɡiɝ meɪk ðə stɛɾɪŋ."

"A stedding," Elyas roared. "You never listen to stories? Of course, there hasn't been an Ogier here in three thousand odd years, not since the Breaking of the World, but it's the stedding makes the Ogier, not the Ogier make the stedding."

"dʒʌst ə lɛdʒənd," pɛɹɪn stæmɝd. ɪn ðə stɔɹiz, ðə stɛɾɪŋ wɝ ɔlweɪz heɪvənz, pleɪsəz tə haɪd, wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz fɹəm ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ fɹəm kɹitʃɝz ə ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz.

"Just a legend," Perrin stammered. In the stories, the stedding were always havens, places to hide, whether it was from Aes Sedai or from creatures of the Father of Lies.

ɛlaɪəs stʃɹeɪɾənd; ɪf nɑɾ ɪɡzækli fɹɛʃ, hi ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ðəɾ i hæd spɛn moʊst ʌv ə deɪ ɹʌnɪŋ. "kʌm ɑn. wid bɛɾɝ ɡɛt dipɝ ɪndə ðɪs lɛdʒənd. ðə ɹeɪvənz kæn fɑloʊ, bʌt ðeɪ kən stɪl si əs ðɪs kloʊs tə ði ɛdʒ, ən ðəɹ kəd bi ɪnʌf ə ðɛm tə wɑtʃ ðə hoʊl bɔɹɾɝ ʌv ɪt. lɛɾ əm kip hʌntɪŋ ɹaɪɾ ɑn baɪ ɪt."

Elyas straightened; if not exactly fresh, he gave no sign that he had spent most of a day running. "Come on. We'd better get deeper into this legend. The ravens can't follow, but they can still see us this close to the edge, and there could be enough of them to watch the whole border of it. Let them keep hunting right on by it."

pɛɹɪn wɑntəd tə steɪ ɹaɪt ðɛɹ, naʊ ðəɾ i wɑz stɑpt; hɪz lɛɡz tʃɹɛmbəld ən toʊld ɪm tə laɪ daʊn fəɹ ə wik. wʌtɛvɝ ɹəfɹɛʃmən i hæd fɛl hæd bɪn moʊməntɛɹi; ɔl ðə wɪɹinəs ən eɪks wɝ bæk. hi fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə teɪk wʌn stɛp, ðən ənʌðɝ. ɪt dɪd nɑt ɡɛɾ iziɝ, bʌɾ i kɛpt əɾ ɪt. ɛɡwin flæp ðə ɹeɪnz tə ɡɛt bɛlə muvɪŋ əɡɛn. ɛlaɪəs sɛɾəld ɪndə ən ɛfɝtləs loʊp, oʊnli sloʊɪŋ tə ə wɔk wən ɪt bɪkeɪm əpɛɹən ði ʌðɝz kəd nɑt kip ʌp. ə fæst wɔk.

Perrin wanted to stay right there, now that he was stopped; his legs trembled and told him to lie down for a week. Whatever refreshment he had felt had been momentary; all the weariness and aches were back. He forced himself to take one step, then another. It did not get easier, but he kept at it. Egwene flapped the reins to get Bela moving again. Elyas settled into an effortless lope, only slowing to a walk when it became apparent the others could not keep up. A fast walk.

"waɪ doʊnt - wi steɪ hɪɹ?" pɛɹɪn pæntɪd. hi wɑz bɹiðɪŋ θɹu hɪz maʊθ, ən i fɔɹs ðə wɝdz aʊt bɪtwin dip, ɹækɪŋ bɹɛθs. "ɪf ɪts ɹɪli - ə stɛɾɪŋ. wid bi seɪf. noʊ tʃɹɑləks. noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ. waɪ doʊnt wi - dʒʌst steɪ hɪɹ - əntɪl ɪts ɔl oʊvɝ?" meɪbi ðə wʊlvz woʊn kʌm hɪɹ, iðɝ.

"Why don't - we stay here?" Perrin panted. He was breathing through his mouth, and he forced the words out between deep, wracking breaths. "If it's really - a stedding. We'd be safe. No Trollocs. No Aes Sedai. Why don't we - just stay here - until it's all over?" Maybe the wolves won't come here, either.

"haʊ lɔŋ wɪl ðət bi?" ɛlaɪəs lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ wɪð wʌn aɪbɹaʊ ɹeɪzd. "wʌt wəd jə it? ɡɹæs, laɪk ðə hɔɹs? bɪsaɪdz, ðɛɹz ʌðɝz noʊ əbaʊt ðɪs pleɪs, ən nʌθɪŋ kips mɛn aʊt, nɑɾ ivən ðə wɝst ə ðɛm. ən ðəɹ ɪz oʊnli wʌn pleɪs wɛɹ ðɛɹz stɪl wɔɾɝ tə bi faʊnd." fɹaʊnɪŋ ənizəli, hi tɝn ɪn ə kəmplit sɝkəl, skænɪŋ ðə lænd. wən i wɑz dʌn, hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ən mʌɾɝd tə hɪmsɛlf. pɛɹɪn fɛlt ɪm kɔlɪŋ tə ðə wʊlvz. hɝi. hɝi. "wi teɪk əɹ tʃænsəz ɑn ə tʃɔɪs ʌv ivəlz, ən ðə ɹeɪvənz ɑɹ ʃʊɹ. kʌm ɑn. ɪts oʊnli ənʌðɝ maɪl əɹ tu."

"How long will that be?" Elyas looked over his shoulder with one eyebrow raised. "What would you eat? Grass, like the horse? Besides, there's others know about this place, and nothing keeps men out, not even the worst of them. And there is only one place where there's still water to be found." Frowning uneasily, he turned in a complete circle, scanning the land. When he was done, he shook his head and muttered to himself. Perrin felt him calling to the wolves. Hurry. Hurry. "We take our chances on a choice of evils, and the ravens are sure. Come on. It's only another mile or two."

pɛɹɪn wʊɾə ɡɹoʊn ɪf i hæd bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə spɛɹ ðə bɹɛθ.

Perrin would have groaned if he had been willing to spare the breath.

hjudʒ boʊldɝz bɪɡæn tə dɑt ðə loʊ hɪlz, ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ lʌmps ʌv ɡɹeɪ, laɪkən-koʊɾəd stoʊn hæf bɛɹiɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, səm əz bɪɡ əz ə haʊs. bɹæmbəlz wɛb ðɛm, ən loʊ bɹʌʃ hæf hɪd moʊst. hɪɹ ən ðəɹ əmɪd ðə dɪsɪkeɪɾɪd bɹaʊn ə bɹæmbəlz ən bɹʌʃ ə loʊn ɡɹin ʃuɾ ənaʊns ðət ðɪs wɑz ə spɛʃəl pleɪs. wʌtɛvɝ wundəd ðə læn bɪɑn ɪts bɔɹɾɝz hɝɾ ɪt, tu, bʌt hɪɹ ðə waʊn dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ kwaɪɾ əz dip.

Huge boulders began to dot the low hills, irregular lumps of gray, lichen-coated stone half buried in the ground, some as big as a house. Brambles webbed them, and low brush half hid most. Here and there amid the desiccated brown of brambles and brush a lone green shoot announced that this was a special place. Whatever wounded the land beyond its borders hurt it, too, but here the wound did not go quite as deep.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðeɪ stʃɹæɡəld oʊvɝ wʌn mɔɹ ɹaɪz, ən ət ðə beɪs ə ðɪs hɪl leɪ ə pul ʌv wɔɾɝ. ɛni ʌv əm cʊɾə weɪɾɪd əkɹɔs ɪɾ ɪn tu stʃɹaɪdz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz klɪɹ ən klin ɪnʌf tə ʃoʊ ðə sændi bɑɾəm laɪk ə ʃiɾ ʌv ɡlæs. ivən ɛlaɪəs hɝiɾ iɡɝli daʊn ðə sloʊp.

Eventually they straggled over one more rise, and at the base of this hill lay a pool of water. Any of them could have waded across it in two strides, but it was clear and clean enough to show the sandy bottom like a sheet of glass. Even Elyas hurried eagerly down the slope.

pɛɹɪn θɹu hɪmsɛlf fʊl lɛŋθ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd wən i ɹitʃt ðə pul ən plʌnʒd ɪz hɛɾ ɪn. ən ɪnstən leɪɾɝ i wɑz spləɾɝɪŋ fɹəm ðə koʊld ʌv wɔɾɝ ðət hæd wɛld ʌp fɹəm ðə dɛpθs ə ði ɝθ. hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, hɪz lɔŋ hɛɹ spɹeɪɪŋ ə ɹeɪn ə dʒɹɑps. ɛɡwin ɡɹɪn ən splæʃt bæk ət hɪm. pɛɹɪnz aɪz ɡɹu soʊbɝ. ʃi fɹaʊn ən oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌɾ i stʌk ɪz feɪs bæk ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ. noʊ kwɛstʃənz. nɑt naʊ. noʊ ɛkspləneɪʃənz. nɑɾ ɛvɝ. bʌɾ ə smɔl vɔɪs tɔntɪd hɪm. bʌt jə wʊɾə dʌn ɪt, wʊdn ju?

Perrin threw himself full length on the ground when he reached the pool and plunged his head in. An instant later he was spluttering from the cold of water that had welled up from the depths of the earth. He shook his head, his long hair spraying a rain of drops. Egwene grinned and splashed back at him. Perrin's eyes grew sober. She frowned and opened her mouth, but he stuck his face back in the water. No questions. Not now. No explanations. Not ever. But a small voice taunted him. But you would have done it, wouldn't you?

ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɛlaɪəs kɔld əm əweɪ fɹəm ðə pul. "ɛnibəɾi wɑns tə it, aɪ wɑn səm hɛlp."

Eventually Elyas called them away from the pool. "Anybody wants to eat, I want some help."

ɛɡwin wɝk tʃɪɹfəli, læfɪŋ ən dʒoʊkɪŋ əz ðeɪ pɹipɛɹd ðɛɹ skænti mil. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ lɛf bʌt tʃiz ən dʒɹaɪd mit; ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ tʃæns tə hʌnt. ət lis ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ti. pɛɹɪn dɪɾ ɪz ʃɛɹ, bʌt saɪlənli. hi fɛlt ɛɡwinz aɪz ɑn hɪm, sɔ ɡɹoʊɪŋ wɝi ɑn əɹ feɪs, bʌɾ i əvɔɪɾəd miɾɪŋ əɹ aɪz əz mʌtʃ əz i kʊd. hɝ læftɝ feɪɾəd, ən ðə dʒoʊks keɪm fɝðɝ əpɑɹt, itʃ wʌn mɔɹ stʃɹeɪn ðən ðə læst. ɛlaɪəs wɑtʃt, seɪɪŋ nʌθɪŋ. ə sɑmbɝ mud dɪsɛndəd, ən ðeɪ bɪɡæn ðɛɹ mil ɪn saɪləns. ðə sʌn ɡɹu ɹɛɾ ɪn ðə wɛst, ən ðɛɹ ʃædoʊz stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt lɔŋ ən θɪn.

Egwene worked cheerfully, laughing and joking as they prepared their scanty meal. There was nothing left but cheese and dried meat; there had been no chance to hunt. At least there was still tea. Perrin did his share, but silently. He felt Egwene's eyes on him, saw growing worry on her face, but he avoided meeting her eyes as much as he could. Her laughter faded, and the jokes came further apart, each one more strained than the last. Elyas watched, saying nothing. A somber mood descended, and they began their meal in silence. The sun grew red in the west, and their shadows stretched out long and thin.

nɑt kwaɪɾ ən aʊɝ tɪl dɑɹk. ɪf nɑt fəɹ ðə stɛɾɪŋ, ɔl ə jə wəd bi dɛd naʊ. wəd juv seɪv hɝ? wəd juv kʌɾ əɹ daʊn laɪk soʊ mɛni bʊʃəz? bʊʃəz doʊn blid, də ðeɪ? əɹ skɹim, ən lʊk ɪn jəɹ aɪz ən æsk, waɪ?

Not quite an hour till dark. If not for the stedding, all of you would be dead now. Would you have saved her? Would you have cut her down like so many bushes? Bushes don't bleed, do they? Or scream, and look in your eyes and ask, why?

pɛɹɪn dʒɹu ɪn ɑn hɪmsɛlf mɔɹ. hi kəd fil sʌmθɪŋ læfɪŋ ət hɪm, dip ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪnd. sʌmθɪŋ kɹuəl. nɑt ðə dɑɹk wʌn. hi ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt ɪt wɑz. nɑt ðə dɑɹk wʌn; hɪmsɛlf.

Perrin drew in on himself more. He could feel something laughing at him, deep in the back of his mind. Something cruel. Not the Dark One. He almost wished it was. Not the Dark One; himself.

fəɹ wʌns ɛlaɪəs hæd bɹoʊkən ɪz ɹul əbaʊt faɪɝz. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ tʃɹiz, bʌɾ i hæd snæp dɛd bɹæntʃəz fɹəm ðə bɹʌʃ ən bɪlt ɪz faɪɝ əɡɛnst ə hjudʒ tʃʌŋk ə ɹɑk stɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə hɪlsaɪd. fɹəm ðə leɪɝz ə sʊt steɪnɪŋ ðə stoʊn, pɛɹɪn θɔt ðə saɪt mʌst əv bɪn juz baɪ dʒɛnɝeɪʃən æftɝ dʒɛnɝeɪʃən ə tʃɹævəlɝz.

For once Elyas had broken his rule about fires. There were no trees, but he had snapped dead branches from the brush and built his fire against a huge chunk of rock sticking out of the hillside. From the layers of soot staining the stone, Perrin thought the site must have been used by generation after generation of travelers.

wʌt ʃoʊɾ əbʌv ɡɹaʊn ə ðə bɪɡ ɹɑk wɑz ɹaʊndəd sʌmwʌt, wɪð ə ʃɑɹp bɹeɪk ɑn wʌn saɪd wɛɹ mɔs, oʊld ən bɹaʊn, kʌvɝd ðə ɹæɡəd sɝfəs. ðə ɡɹuvz ən hɑloʊz ɪɹoʊɾəd ɪn ðə ɹaʊndəd pɑɹt lʊkt ɑd tə pɛɹɪn, bʌɾ i wɑz tu əbzɔɹbd ɪn ɡlum tə wʌndɝ əbaʊɾ ɪt. ɛɡwin, ðoʊ, stʌɾid ɪɾ əz ʃi eɪt.

What showed above ground of the big rock was rounded somewhat, with a sharp break on one side where moss, old and brown, covered the ragged surface. The grooves and hollows eroded in the rounded part looked odd to Perrin, but he was too absorbed in gloom to wonder about it. Egwene, though, studied it as she ate.

"ðæt," ʃi sɛd faɪnəli, "lʊks laɪk ən aɪ." pɛɹɪn blɪŋkt; ɪt dɪd lʊk laɪk ən aɪ, ʌndɝ ɔl ðət sʊt.

"That," she said finally, "looks like an eye." Perrin blinked; it did look like an eye, under all that soot.

"ɪɾ ɪz," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. hi sæt wɪð ɪz bæk tə ðə faɪɝ ən ðə ɹɑk, stʌɾiɪŋ ðə læn ɝaʊn əm waɪl i tʃuɾ ə stʃɹɪp ə dʒɹaɪd miɾ ɔlmoʊst əz tʌf əz lɛðɝ. "ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz aɪ. ði aɪ ʌv ðə haɪ kɪŋ hɪmsɛlf. ðɪs ɪz wʌɾ ɪz paʊɝ ən ɡlɔɹi keɪm tə, ɪn ði ɛnd." hi sɛɾ ɪɾ æbsənli. ivən ɪz tʃuɪŋ wɑz æbsəntmaɪndɪd; hɪz aɪz ən ɪz ətɛnʃən wɝ ɑn ðə hɪlz.

"It is," Elyas said. He sat with his back to the fire and the rock, studying the land around them while he chewed a strip of dried meat almost as tough as leather. "Artur Hawkwing's eye. The eye of the High King himself. This is what his power and glory came to, in the end." He said it absently. Even his chewing was absentminded; his eyes and his attention were on the hills.

"ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ!" ɛɡwin ɪkskleɪmd. "jɔɹ dʒoʊkɪŋ wɪð mi. ɪɾ ɪzən ən aɪ əɾ ɔl. waɪ wəd sʌmbɑɾi kɑɹv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz aɪ ɑn ə ɹɑk aʊt hɪɹ?"

"Artur Hawkwing!" Egwene exclaimed. "You're joking with me. It isn't an eye at all. Why would somebody carve Artur Hawkwing's eye on a rock out here?"

ɛlaɪəs ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət hɝ, mʌɾɝɪŋ, "wʌt də ðeɪ titʃ jə vɪlədʒ wɛlps?" hi snɔɹɾɪd ən stʃɹeɪɾənd bæk tə hɪz wɑtʃɪŋ, bʌɾ i wɛn ɑn tɔkɪŋ. "ɑɹɾɝ pɛndʒɹæɡ tænɹəl, ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ, ðə haɪ kɪŋ, junaɪɾəd ɔl ðə lænz fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt tə ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, fɹəm ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən tə ði il weɪst, ən ivən səm bɪɑn ðə weɪst. hi ivən sɛn ɑɹmiz ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. ðə stɔɹiz seɪ hi ɹul ðə hoʊl wɝld, bʌt wʌɾ i ɹɪli dɪd ɹul wɑz ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛni mæn aʊtsaɪɾ ʌv ə stɔɹi. ən i bɹɔt pis ən dʒʌstəs tə ðə lænd."

Elyas glanced over his shoulder at her, muttering, "What do they teach you village whelps?" He snorted and straightened back to his watching, but he went on talking. "Artur Paendrag Tanreall, Artur Hawkwing, the High King, united all the lands from the Great Blight to the Sea of Storms, from the Aryth Ocean to the Aiel Waste, and even some beyond the Waste. He even sent armies the other side of the Aryth Ocean. The stories say he ruled the whole world, but what he really did rule was enough for any man outside of a story. And he brought peace and justice to the land."

"ɔl stʊɾ ikwəl bɪfɔɹ ðə lɔ," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ænd noʊ mæn ɹeɪzd ɪz hæn əɡɛnst ənʌðɝ."

"All stood equal before the law," Egwene said, "and no man raised his hand against another."

"soʊ juv hɝd ðə stɔɹiz, ət list." ɛlaɪəs tʃʌkəld, ə dʒɹaɪ saʊnd. "ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ bɹɔt pis ən dʒʌstəs, bʌɾ i dɪɾ ɪt wɪð faɪɝ ən sɔɹd. ə tʃaɪl kəd ɹaɪɾ əloʊn wɪð ə bæɡ ʌv ɡoʊl fɹəm ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən tə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld ən nɛvɝ əv ə moʊməns fɪɹ, bʌt ðə haɪ kɪŋz dʒʌstəs wɑz əz hɑɹɾ əz ðət ɹɑk ðəɹ fəɹ ɛniwʌn u tʃælənʒd ɪz paʊɝ, ivən ɪf ɪt wɑz dʒʌs baɪ biɪŋ u ðeɪ wɝ, əɹ baɪ pipəl θɪŋkɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ ə tʃælənʒ. ðə kɑmən foʊk hæd pis, ən dʒʌstəs, ən fʊl bɛliz, bʌɾ i leɪɾ ə twɛnti-jɪɹ sidʒ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn ən pʊɾ ə pɹaɪs ʌv ə θaʊzənd ɡoʊl kɹaʊnz ɑn ðə hɛɾ ʌv ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"So you've heard the stories, at least." Elyas chuckled, a dry sound. "Artur Hawkwing brought peace and justice, but he did it with fire and sword. A child could ride alone with a bag of gold from the Aryth Ocean to the Spine of the World and never have a moment's fear, but the High King's justice was as hard as that rock there for anyone who challenged his power, even if it was just by being who they were, or by people thinking they were a challenge. The common folk had peace, and justice, and full bellies, but he laid a twenty-year siege to Tar Valon and put a price of a thousand gold crowns on the head of every Aes Sedai."

"aɪ θɔt jə dɪdn laɪk ɛɛs sədaɪ," ɛɡwin sɛd.

"I thought you didn't like Aes Sedai," Egwene said.

ɛlaɪəs ɡeɪv ə ɹaɪ smaɪl. "dʌzn mæɾɝ wʌɾ aɪ laɪk, ɡɝl. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ wɑz ə pɹaʊd ful. ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hilɝ cʊɾə seɪvd ɪm wən i tʊk sɪk - əɹ wɑz pɔɪzənd, əz səm seɪ - bʌɾ ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ stɪl əlaɪv wɑz pɛn ʌp bɪhaɪn ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ wɔlz, juzɪŋ ɔl ðɛɹ paʊɝ tə hoʊld ɔf ən ɑɹmi ðət lɪɾ ʌp ðə naɪt wɪð ðɛɹ kæmpfaɪɝz. hi wʊdn əv lɛt wʌn nɪɹ hɪm, ɛniweɪ. hi heɪɾəd ɛɛs sədaɪ əz mʌtʃ əz i heɪɾəd ðə dɑɹk wʌn."

Elyas gave a wry smile. "Doesn't matter what I like, girl. Artur Hawkwing was a proud fool. An Aes Sedai healer could have saved him when he took sick - or was poisoned, as some say - but every Aes Sedai still alive was penned up behind the Shining Walls, using all their Power to hold off an army that lit up the night with their campfires. He wouldn't have let one near him, anyway. He hated Aes Sedai as much as he hated the Dark One."

ɛɡwinz maʊθ taɪɾənd, bʌt wən ʃi spoʊk, ɔl ʃi sɛd wɑz, "wʌt dʌz ɔl ðəɾ əv tə də wɪð wɛðɝ ðæts ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz aɪ?"

Egwene's mouth tightened, but when she spoke, all she said was, "What does all that have to do with whether that's Artur Hawkwing's eye?"

"dʒʌs ðɪs, ɡɝl. wɪð pis ɪksɛp fəɹ wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn əkɹɔs ði oʊʃən, wɪð ðə pipəl tʃɪɹɪŋ ɪm wɛɹɛvɝ i wɛnt - ðeɪ ɹɪli lʌv hɪm, jə si; hi wɑz ə hɑɹʃ mæn, bʌt nɛvɝ wɪð ðə kɑmən foʊk - wɛl, wɪð ɔl ə ðæt, hi dɪsaɪɾɪd ɪt wɑz taɪm tə bɪl hɪmsɛlf ə kæpəɾəl. ə nu sɪɾi, nɑt kənɛktəɾ ɪn ɛni mænz maɪnd wɪð ɛni oʊl kɑz əɹ fækʃən əɹ ɹaɪvəlɹi. hɪɹ, hid bɪld ɪt, ət ðə vɛɹi sɛntɝ ə ðə læn bɔɹɾɝd baɪ ðə siz ən ðə weɪst ən ðə blaɪt. hɪɹ, wɛɹ noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ wəɾ ɛvɝ kʌm wɪlɪŋ əɹ kəd juz ðə paʊɝ ɪf ðeɪ dɪd. ə kæpəɾəl fɹəm wɪtʃ, wʌn deɪ, ðə hoʊl wɝld wəd ɹəsiv pis ən dʒʌstəs. wən ðeɪ hɝd ðə pɹɑkləmeɪʃən, ðə kɑmən pipəl səbskɹaɪbd ɪnʌf mʌni tə bɪld ə mɑnjəmən tə hɪm. moʊst ə ðɛm lʊkt ɑn ɪm əz oʊnli ə stɛp bɪloʊ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ. ə ʃɔɹt stɛp. ɪt tʊk faɪv jɪɹz tə kɑɹv ən bɪld. ə stætʃu ʌv hɔkwɪŋ, hɪmsɛlf, ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz bɪɡɝ ðən ðə mæn. ðeɪ ɹeɪzd ɪt ɹaɪt hɪɹ, ən ðə sɪɾi wɑz tə ɹaɪz ɝaʊn ɪt."

"Just this, girl. With peace except for what was going on across the ocean, with the people cheering him wherever he went - they really loved him, you see; he was a harsh man, but never with the common folk - well, with all of that, he decided it was time to build himself a capital. A new city, not connected in any man's mind with any old cause or faction or rivalry. Here, he'd build it, at the very center of the land bordered by the seas and the Waste and the Blight. Here, where no Aes Sedai would ever come willing or could use the Power if they did. A capital from which, one day, the whole world would receive peace and justice. When they heard the proclamation, the common people subscribed enough money to build a monument to him. Most of them looked on him as only a step below the Creator. A short step. It took five years to carve and build. A statue of Hawkwing, himself, a hundred times bigger than the man. They raised it right here, and the city was to rise around it."

"ðɛɹ wɑz nɛvɝ ɛni sɪɾi hɪɹ," ɛɡwin skɔft. "ðɛɹ wəɾ əv tə bi sʌmθɪŋ lɛft ɪf ðəɹ wɑz. sʌmθɪŋ."

"There was never any city here," Egwene scoffed. "There would have to be something left if there was. Something."

ɛlaɪəs nɑɾəd, stɪl kipɪŋ ɪz wɑtʃ. "ɪndid ðəɹ wɑz nɑt. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ daɪd ðə vɛɹi deɪ ðə stætʃu wɑz fɪnɪʃt, ən ɪz sʌnz ən ðə ɹɛst ə hɪz blʌd fɔɾ oʊvɝ u wəd sɪɾ ɑn hɔkwɪŋz θɹoʊn. ðə stætʃu stʊɾ əloʊn ɪn ðə mɪdst ə ðiz hɪlz. ðə sʌnz ən ðə nɛfjuz ən ðə kʌzənz daɪd, ən ðə læst ə ðə hɔkwɪŋz blʌd vænɪʃt fɹəm ði ɝθ - ɪksɛp meɪbi fəɹ səm ə ðoʊz u wɛn oʊvɝ ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən. ðəɹ wɝ ðoʊz u wʊɾə ɪɹeɪst ivən ðə mɛmɹi ʌv hɪm, ɪf ðeɪ kʊd. bʊks wɝ bɝn dʒʌs kəz ðeɪ mɛnʃən ɪz neɪm. ɪn ði ɛn ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ lɛft ə hɪm bʌt ðə stɔɹiz, ən moʊst ə ðɛm ɹɔŋ. ðæts wʌɾ ɪz ɡlɔɹi keɪm tə.

Elyas nodded, still keeping his watch. "Indeed there was not. Artur Hawkwing died the very day the statue was finished, and his sons and the rest of his blood fought over who would sit on Hawkwing's throne. The statue stood alone in the midst of these hills. The sons and the nephews and the cousins died, and the last of the Hawkwing's blood vanished from the earth - except maybe for some of those who went over the Aryth Ocean. There were those who would have erased even the memory of him, if they could. Books were burned just because they mentioned his name. In the end there was nothing left of him but the stories, and most of them wrong. That's what his glory came to.

"ðə faɪɾɪŋ dɪdn stɑp, ʌv kɔɹs, dʒʌs kəz ðə hɔkwɪŋ ən ɪz kɪn wɝ dɛd. ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ə θɹoʊn tə bi wʌn, ən ɛvɹi lɔɹɾ ən leɪɾi hu kəd mʌstɝ faɪɾɪŋ mɛn wɑntəɾ ɪt. ɪt wɑz ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. læstəɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd ən twɛnti-θɹi, ɹɪli, ən moʊst ə ðə hɪstɝi ʌv ðət taɪm ɪz lɔst ɪn ðə smoʊk ə bɝnɪŋ taʊnz. mɛni ɡɑɾ ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə lænd, bʌt nʌn ɡɑt ðə hoʊl, ən sʌmtaɪm dʊɹɪŋ ðoʊz jɪɹz ðə stætʃu wɑz pʊl daʊn. meɪbi ðeɪ kʊdn stæn mɛʒɝɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz əɡɛnst ɪɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ."

"The fighting didn't stop, of course, just because the Hawkwing and his kin were dead. There was still a throne to be won, and every lord and lady who could muster fighting men wanted it. It was the beginning of the War of the Hundred Years. Lasted a hundred and twenty-three, really, and most of the history of that time is lost in the smoke of burning towns. Many got a part of the land, but none got the whole, and sometime during those years the statue was pulled down. Maybe they couldn't stand measuring themselves against it any longer."

"fɝs jə saʊn əz ɪf jə dɪspaɪz hɪm," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ænd naʊ jə saʊn əz ɪf jə ædmaɪɹ hɪm." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

"First you sound as if you despise him," Egwene said, "and now you sound as if you admire him." She shook her head.

ɛlaɪəs tɝn tə lʊk ət hɝ, ə flæt, ənblɪŋkɪŋ stɛɹ. "ɡɛt səm mɔɹ ti naʊ, ɪf jə wɑn ɛni. aɪ wɑn ðə faɪɝ aʊt bɪfɔɹ dɑɹk."

Elyas turned to look at her, a flat, unblinking stare. "Get some more tea now, if you want any. I want the fire out before dark."

pɛɹɪn kəd meɪk aʊt ði aɪ klɪɹli naʊ, dɪspaɪt ðə feɪlɪŋ laɪt. ɪt wɑz bɪɡɝ ðən ə mænz hɛd, ən ðə ʃædoʊz fɔlɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪt meɪɾ ɪt sim laɪk ə ɹeɪvənz aɪ, hɑɹɾ ən blæk ən wɪθaʊt pɪɾi. hi wɪʃt ðeɪ wɝ slipɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ ɛls.

Perrin could make out the eye clearly now, despite the failing light. It was bigger than a man's head, and the shadows falling across it made it seem like a raven's eye, hard and black and without pity. He wished they were sleeping somewhere else.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾi


CHAPTER 30

tʃɪlʒɹən ə ʃædoʊ


Children of Shadow

ɛɡwin sæt baɪ ðə faɪɝ, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət ðə fɹæɡmən ə stætʃu, bʌt pɛɹɪn wɛn daʊn baɪ ðə pul tə bi əloʊn. deɪ wɑz feɪɾɪŋ, ən ðə naɪt wɪnd wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɹaɪzɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ist, ɹʌfəlɪŋ ðə sɝfəs ə ðə wɔɾɝ. hi tʊk ði æks fɹəm ðə lup ɑn ɪz bɛlt ən tɝn ɪɾ oʊvɝ ɪn ɪz hænz. ði æʃwʊd hæft wɑz əz lɔŋ əz ɪz ɑɹm, ən smuð ən kul tə ðə tʌtʃ. hi heɪɾəd ɪt. hi wɑz əʃeɪmd ə haʊ pɹaʊɾ i hæd bɪn ə ði æks bæk ɪn ɛmənz fild. bɪfɔɹ i nu wʌɾ i maɪt bi wɪlɪŋ tə də wɪð ɪt.

Egwene sat by the fire, staring up at the fragment of statue, but Perrin went down by the pool to be alone. Day was fading, and the night wind was already rising out of the east, ruffling the surface of the water. He took the axe from the loop on his belt and turned it over in his hands. The ashwood haft was as long as his arm, and smooth and cool to the touch. He hated it. He was ashamed of how proud he had been of the axe back in Emond's Field. Before he knew what he might be willing to do with it.

"ju heɪɾ əɹ ðət mʌtʃ?" ɛlaɪəs sɛd bɪhaɪn hɪm.

"You hate her that much?" Elyas said behind him.

stɑɹɾəld, hi dʒʌmpt ən hæf ɹeɪz ði æks bɪfɔɹ i sɔ hu ɪt wɑz. "kæn . . . ? kən jə ɹɛd maɪ maɪnd, tu? laɪk ðə wʊlvz?"

Startled, he jumped and half raised the axe before he saw who it was. "Can . . . ? Can you read my mind, too? Like the wolves?"

ɛlaɪəs kɑkt ɪz hɛd tə wʌn saɪɾ ən aɪɾ ɪm kwɪtsɪkli. "ə blaɪn mæn kəd ɹid jəɹ feɪs, bɔɪ. wɛl, spik ʌp. dʒju heɪt ðə ɡɝl? dɪspaɪz hɝ? ðæts ɪt. jə wɝ ɹɛɾi tə kɪl əɹ kəz jə dɪspaɪz hɝ, ɔlweɪz dʒɹæɡɪŋ əɹ fit, hoʊldɪŋ jə bæk wɪð əɹ wʊmənɪʃ weɪz."

Elyas cocked his head to one side and eyed him quizzically. "A blind man could read your face, boy. Well, speak up. Do you hate the girl? Despise her? That's it. You were ready to kill her because you despise her, always dragging her feet, holding you back with her womanish ways."

"ɛɡwin nɛvɝ dʒɹæɡd əɹ fiɾ ɪn əɹ laɪf," hi pɹətɛstəd. "ʃi ɔlweɪz dʌz əɹ ʃɛɹ. aɪ doʊn dɪspaɪz hɝ, aɪ lʌv hɝ." hi ɡlɛɹɾ əɾ ɛlaɪəs, dɛɹɪŋ ɪm tə læf. "nɑt laɪk ðæt. aɪ min, ʃi ɪzən laɪk ə sɪstɝ, bʌt ʃi ən ɹænd. . . . blʌɾ ən æʃəz! ɪf ðə ɹeɪvənz kɑɾ ʌs. . . . ɪf. . . . aɪ doʊnt noʊ."

"Egwene never dragged her feet in her life," he protested. "She always does her share. I don't despise her, I love her." He glared at Elyas, daring him to laugh. "Not like that. I mean, she isn't like a sister, but she and Rand. . . . Blood and ashes! If the ravens caught us. . . . If. . . . I don't know."

"jɛs, jə du. ɪf ʃi hæd tə tʃuz əɹ weɪ ʌv daɪɪŋ, wɪtʃ dʒju θɪŋk ʃid pɪk? wʌn klin bloʊ ʌv jəɹ æks, əɹ ðə weɪ ði ænəməlz wi sɔ tədeɪ daɪd? aɪ noʊ wɪtʃ aɪd teɪk."

"Yes, you do. If she had to choose her way of dying, which do you think she'd pick? One clean blow of your axe, or the way the animals we saw today died? I know which I'd take."

"aɪ doʊn əv ɛni ɹaɪt tə tʃuz fəɹ hɝ. jə woʊn tɛl hɝ, wɪl ju? əbaʊt. . . ." hɪz hænz taɪɾənd ɑn ði æks hæft; ðə mʌsəlz ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz kɔɹɾəd, hɛvi mʌsəlz fəɹ ɪz eɪdʒ, bɪl baɪ lɔŋ aʊɝz swɪŋɪŋ ðə hæmɝ ət mæstɝ luhənz fɔɹdʒ. fəɹ ən ɪnstən i θɔt ðə θɪk wʊɾən ʃæft wəd snæp. "aɪ heɪt ðɪs blʌɾi θɪŋ," hi ɡɹaʊld. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ aɪm duɪŋ wɪð ɪt, stʃɹʌɾɪŋ ɝaʊn laɪk səm kaɪndə ful. aɪ kʊdn əv dʌn ɪt, jə noʊ. wən ɪt wɑz ɔl pɹitɛn ən meɪbi, aɪ kəd swæɡɝ, ən pleɪ əz ɪf aɪ. . . ." hi saɪd, hɪz vɔɪs feɪɾɪŋ. "ɪts dɪfɹənt, naʊ. aɪ doʊn ɛvɝ wɑnə juz ɪɾ əɡɛn."

"I don't have any right to choose for her. You won't tell her, will you? About. . . ." His hands tightened on the axe haft; the muscles in his arms corded, heavy muscles for his age, built by long hours swinging the hammer at Master Luhhan's forge. For an instant he thought the thick wooden shaft would snap. "I hate this bloody thing," he growled. "I don't know what I'm doing with it, strutting around like some kind of fool. I couldn't have done it, you know. When it was all pretend and maybe, I could swagger, and play as if I. . . ." He sighed, his voice fading. "It's different, now. I don't ever want to use it again."

"jul juz ɪt."

"You'll use it."

pɛɹɪn ɹeɪz ði æks tə θɹoʊ ɪɾ ɪn ðə pul, bʌɾ ɛlaɪəs kɑɾ ɪz ɹɪst.

Perrin raised the axe to throw it in the pool, but Elyas caught his wrist.

"jul juz ɪt, bɔɪ, ən əz lɔŋ əz jə heɪt juzɪŋ ɪt, jəl juz ɪt mɔɹ waɪzli ðən moʊs mɛn wʊd. weɪt. ɪf ɛvɝ jə doʊn heɪɾ ɪɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, ðən wɪl bi ðə taɪm tə θɹoʊ ɪɾ əz fɑɹ əz jə kən ən ɹʌn ði ʌðɝ weɪ."

"You'll use it, boy, and as long as you hate using it, you will use it more wisely than most men would. Wait. If ever you don't hate it any longer, then will be the time to throw it as far as you can and run the other way."

pɛɹɪn hɛftəd ði æks ɪn ɪz hænz, stɪl tɛmptəd tə liv ɪɾ ɪn ðə pul. izi fəɹ ɪm tə seɪ weɪt. wʌɾ ɪf aɪ weɪɾ ən ðən kæn θɹoʊ ɪɾ əweɪ?

Perrin hefted the axe in his hands, still tempted to leave it in the pool. Easy for him to say wait. What if I wait and then can't throw it away?

hi oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə æsk ɛlaɪəs, bʌt noʊ wɝdz keɪm aʊt. ə sɛndɪŋ fɹəm ðə wʊlvz, soʊ ɝdʒən ðəɾ ɪz aɪz ɡleɪzd oʊvɝ. fəɹ ən ɪnstən i fɝɡɑt wʌɾ i hæd bɪn ɡoʊɪŋ tə seɪ, fɝɡɑɾ i hæd bɪn gɑnə seɪ ɛniθɪŋ, fɝɡɑɾ ivən haʊ tə spik, haʊ tə bɹið. ɛlaɪəsəz feɪs sæɡd, tu, ən ɪz aɪz sim tə pɪɹ ɪnwɝɾ ən fɑɹ əweɪ. ðən ɪt wɑz ɡɔn, əz kwɪkli əz ɪt hæd kʌm. ɪt hæɾ oʊnli læstəɾ ə hɑɹtbit, bʌt ðət wɑz ɪnʌf.

He opened his mouth to ask Elyas, but no words came out. A sending from the wolves, so urgent that his eyes glazed over. For an instant he forgot what he had been going to say, forgot he had been going to say anything, forgot even how to speak, how to breathe. Elyas's face sagged, too, and his eyes seemed to peer inward and far away. Then it was gone, as quickly as it had come. It had only lasted a heartbeat, but that was enough.

pɛɹɪn ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf ən fɪld ɪz lʌŋz dipli. ɛlaɪəs dɪd nɑt pɔz; əz sun əz ðə veɪl lɪftəd fɹəm ɪz aɪz, hi spɛd təwɔɹd ðə faɪɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɛni hɛzəteɪʃən. pɛɹɪn ɹæn wɝdləsli bɪhaɪn hɪm.

Perrin shook himself and filled his lungs deeply. Elyas did not pause; as soon as the veil lifted from his eyes, he sped toward the fire without any hesitation. Perrin ran wordlessly behind him.

"daʊs ðə faɪɝ!" ɛlaɪəs kɔl hɔɹsli tə ɛɡwin. hi dʒɛstʃɝɾ ɝdʒənli, ən i sim tə bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʃaʊɾ ɪn ə wɪspɝ. "ɡɛɾ ɪɾ aʊt!"

"Douse the fire!" Elyas called hoarsely to Egwene. He gestured urgently, and he seemed to be trying to shout in a whisper. "Get it out!"

ʃi ɹoʊz tə hɝ fit, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm ənsɝteɪnli, ðən stɛp kloʊsɝ tə ðə faɪɝ, bʌt sloʊli, klɪɹli nɑɾ ʌndɝstændɪŋ wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ.

She rose to her feet, staring at him uncertainly, then stepped closer to the fire, but slowly, clearly not understanding what was happening.

ɛlaɪəs pʊʃt ɹʌfli pæst əɹ ən snætʃt ʌp ðə ti kɛɾəl, kɝsɪŋ wən ɪt bɝn hɪm. dʒʌɡəlɪŋ ðə hɑt pɑt, hi ʌpɛndəɾ ɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə faɪɝ dʒʌs ðə seɪm. ə stɛp bɪhaɪn hɪm, pɛɹɪn ɝaɪvd ɪn taɪm tə stɑɹt kɪkɪŋ dɝɾ oʊvɝ ðə hɪsɪŋ koʊlz əz ðə læst ə ðə ti splæʃt ɪndə ðə faɪɝ, hɪsɪŋ ən ɹaɪzɪŋ ɪn tɛnʒɹəlz ə stim. hi dɪd nɑt stɑp əntɪl ðə læs vɛstɪdʒ ə ðə faɪɝ wɑz bɛɹid.

Elyas pushed roughly past her and snatched up the tea kettle, cursing when it burned him. Juggling the hot pot, he upended it over the fire just the same. A step behind him, Perrin arrived in time to start kicking dirt over the hissing coals as the last of the tea splashed into the fire, hissing and rising in tendrils of steam. He did not stop until the last vestige of the fire was buried.

ɛlaɪəs tɔs ðə kɛɾəl tə pɛɹɪn, hu ɪmiɾiətli lɛɾ ɪt fɔl wɪð ə tʃoʊkt-ɔf jɛl. pɛɹɪn blu ɑn ɪz hænz, fɹaʊnɪŋ əɾ ɛlaɪəs, bʌt ðə fɝ-klæd mæn wɑz tu bɪzi ɡɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ kæmpsaɪɾ ə heɪsti lʊk tə peɪ ɛni ətɛnʃən.

Elyas tossed the kettle to Perrin, who immediately let it fall with a choked-off yell. Perrin blew on his hands, frowning at Elyas, but the fur-clad man was too busy giving their campsite a hasty look to pay any attention.

"noʊ tʃæns tə haɪd ðət sʌmbɑɾiz bɪn hɪɹ," ɛlaɪəs sɛd. "wil dʒʌst əv tə hɝi ən hoʊp. meɪbi ðeɪ woʊn bɑðɝ. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, bʌɾ aɪ wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz ðə ɹeɪvənz."

"No chance to hide that somebody's been here," Elyas said. "We'll just have to hurry and hope. Maybe they won't bother. Blood and ashes, but I was sure it was the ravens."

hɝidli pɛɹɪn tɔs ðə sæɾəl ɑn bɛlə, pɹɑpɪŋ ði æks əɡɛnst ɪz θaɪ waɪl i bɛn tə taɪɾən ðə ɡɝθ.

Hurriedly Perrin tossed the saddle on Bela, propping the axe against his thigh while he bent to tighten the girth.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" ɛɡwin æskt. hɝ vɔɪs ʃʊk. "tʃɹɑləks? eɪ feɪd?"

"What is it?" Egwene asked. Her voice shook. "Trollocs? A Fade?"

"ɡoʊ ist əɹ wɛst," ɛlaɪəs toʊl pɛɹɪn. "faɪn ə pleɪs tə haɪd, ən əl dʒɔɪn jə əz sun əz aɪ kæn. ɪf ðeɪ si ə wʊlf. . . ." hi dɑɹɾɪd əweɪ, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf i ɪntɛndəd tə ɡoʊ tə ɔl fɔɹz, ən vænɪʃt ɪndə ðə lɛŋθənɪŋ ʃædoʊz ʌv ivnɪŋ.

"Go east or west," Elyas told Perrin. "Find a place to hide, and I'll join you as soon as I can. If they see a wolf. . . ." He darted away, crouching almost as if he intended to go to all fours, and vanished into the lengthening shadows of evening.

ɛɡwin heɪstəli ɡæðɝɾ əɹ fju bɪlɔŋɪŋz, bʌt ʃi stɪl dɪmændəɾ ən ɛkspləneɪʃən fɹəm pɛɹɪn. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz ɪnsɪstən ən ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ fɹaɪɾənd baɪ ðə mɪnəɾ əz i kɛp saɪlənt. hi wɑz fɹaɪɾənd, tu, bʌt fɪɹ meɪɾ əm muv fæstɝ. hi weɪɾəd əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ hɛɾəd təwɔɹd ðə sɛɾɪŋ sʌn. tʃɹɑɾɪŋ əhɛɾ ə bɛlə ən hoʊldɪŋ ði æks əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst ɪn boʊθ hænz, hi toʊld wʌɾ i nu oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ɪn snætʃɪz waɪl hʌntɪŋ fəɹ ə pleɪs tə ɡoʊ tə ɡɹaʊn ən weɪt fəɹ ɛlaɪəs.

Egwene hastily gathered her few belongings, but she still demanded an explanation from Perrin. Her voice was insistent and growing more frightened by the minute as he kept silent. He was frightened, too, but fear made them move faster. He waited until they were headed toward the setting sun. Trotting ahead of Bela and holding the axe across his chest in both hands, he told what he knew over his shoulder in snatches while hunting for a place to go to ground and wait for Elyas.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ ə lɑɾ ə mɛn kʌmɪŋ, ɑn hɔɹsəz. ðeɪ keɪm ʌp bɪhaɪn ðə wʊlvz, bʌt ðə mɛn dɪdn si ðɛm. ðəɹ hɛɾɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə pul. pɹɑbli ðeɪ doʊn əv ɛniθɪŋ tə də wɪð ʌs; ɪts ði oʊnli wɔɾɝ fəɹ maɪlz. bʌt dæpəl sɛz. . . ." hi ɡlænst oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. ði ivnɪŋ sʌn peɪntəɾ ɑd ʃædoʊz ɑn əɹ feɪs, ʃædoʊz ðət hɪɾ əɹ ɪkspɹɛʃən. wʌɾ ɪz ʃi θɪŋkɪŋ? ɪz ʃi lʊkɪŋ ət jə əz ɪf ʃi dʌznt noʊ jə ɛnimɔɹ? dʌz ʃi noʊ ju? "dæpəl sɛz ðeɪ smɛl ɹɔŋ. ɪts . . . sɔɹɾ ə ðə weɪ ə ɹæbɪd dɔɡ smɛlz ɹɔŋ." ðə pul wɑz lɔs tə saɪt bɪhaɪn ðɛm. hi kəd stɪl pɪk aʊt boʊldɝz - fɹæɡməns ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz stætʃu - ɪn ðə dipənɪŋ twaɪlaɪt, bʌt nɑt tə tɛl wɪtʃ wɑz ðə stoʊn wɛɹ ðə faɪɝ hæd bɪn. "wil steɪ əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm, faɪn ə pleɪs tə weɪt fəɹ ɛlaɪəs."

"There are a lot of men coming, on horses. They came up behind the wolves, but the men didn't see them. They're heading toward the pool. Probably they don't have anything to do with us; it's the only water for miles. But Dapple says. . . ." He glanced over his shoulder. The evening sun painted odd shadows on her face, shadows that hid her expression. What is she thinking? Is she looking at you as if she doesn't know you anymore? Does she know you? "Dapple says they smell wrong. It's . . . sort of the way a rabid dog smells wrong." The pool was lost to sight behind them. He could still pick out boulders - fragments of Artur Hawkwing's statue - in the deepening twilight, but not to tell which was the stone where the fire had been. "We'll stay away from them, find a place to wait for Elyas."

"waɪ ʃəd ðeɪ bɑðɝ ʌs?" ʃi dɪmændəd. "wɝ səpoʊz tə bi seɪf hɪɹ. ɪts səpoʊz tə bi seɪf. laɪt, ðəɹ əz tə bi sʌmpleɪs seɪf."

"Why should they bother us?" she demanded. "We're supposed to be safe here. It's supposed to be safe. Light, there has to be someplace safe."

pɛɹɪn bɪɡæn lʊkɪŋ hɑɹɾɝ fəɹ sʌmwɛɹ tə haɪd. ðeɪ kəd nɑt bi vɛɹi fɑɹ fɹəm ðə pul, bʌt ðə twaɪlaɪt wɑz θɪkənɪŋ. sun ɪt wəd bi tu dɑɹk tə tʃɹævəl. feɪn laɪt stɪl beɪðd ðə kɹɛsts. fɹəm ðə hɑloʊz bɪtwin, wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz bɛɹli ɪnʌf tə si, ɪt sim bɹaɪt baɪ kɑntʃɹæst. ɔf tə ðə lɛft ə dɑɹk ʃeɪp stʊd ʃɑɹp əɡɛns ðə skaɪ, ə lɑɹdʒ, flæt stoʊn slæntɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə hɪlsaɪd, kloʊkɪŋ ðə sloʊp bɪniθ ɪn dɑɹknəs.

Perrin began looking harder for somewhere to hide. They could not be very far from the pool, but the twilight was thickening. Soon it would be too dark to travel. Faint light still bathed the crests. From the hollows between, where there was barely enough to see, it seemed bright by contrast. Off to the left a dark shape stood sharp against the sky, a large, flat stone slanting out of a hillside, cloaking the slope beneath in darkness.

"ðɪs weɪ," hi sɛd.

"This way," he said.

hi tʃɹɑɾəd təwɔɹd ðə hɪl, ɡlænsɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ fəɹ ɛni saɪn ə ðə mɛn u wɝ kʌmɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ - jɛt. mɔɹ ðən wʌns i hæd tə stɑp ən weɪt waɪl ði ʌðɝz stʌmbəld æftɝ hɪm. ɛɡwin wɑz kɹaʊtʃt oʊvɝ bɛləz nɛk, ən ðə mɛɹ wɑz pɪkɪŋ əɹ weɪ kɛɹfəli oʊvɝ ði ənivən ɡɹaʊnd. pɛɹɪn θɔt ðeɪ boʊθ mʌs bi mɔɹ taɪɝd ðən i hæd bɪlivd. ðɪs hæd bɛɾɝ bi ə ɡʊd haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk wi kən hʌn fəɹ ənʌðɝ.

He trotted toward the hill, glancing over his shoulder for any sign of the men who were coming. There was nothing - yet. More than once he had to stop and wait while the others stumbled after him. Egwene was crouched over Bela's neck, and the mare was picking her way carefully over the uneven ground. Perrin thought they both must be more tired than he had believed. This had better be a good hiding place. I don't think we can hunt for another.

ət ðə beɪs ə ðə hɪl i stʌɾid ðə mæsɪv, flæt ɹɑk aʊtlaɪn əɡɛns ðə skaɪ, dʒʌɾɪŋ aʊt ðə sloʊp ɔlmoʊst ət ðə kɹɛst. ðəɹ wɑz ən ɑd fəmɪljɛɹəɾi tə ðə weɪ ðə tɑp ə ðə hjudʒ slæb sim tə fɔɹm ɪɹɛɡjəlɝ stɛps, θɹi ʌp ən wʌn daʊn. hi klaɪm ðə ʃɔɹt dɪstəns ən fɛlt əkɹɔs ðə stoʊn, wɔkɪŋ əlɔŋ ɪt. dɪspaɪt ðə wɛðɝɪŋ ə sɛntʃɝiz i kəd stɪl fil fɔɹ dʒɔɪn kɑləmz. hi ɡlænst ʌp ət ðə stɛp-laɪk tɑp ə ðə stoʊn, taʊɝɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd laɪk ə hjudʒ lin-tə. fɪŋɡɝz. wɪl ʃɛltɝ ɪn ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz hænd. meɪbi səm ə hɪz dʒʌstəs ɪz lɛf hɪɹ.

At the base of the hill he studied the massive, flat rock outlined against the sky, jutting out the slope almost at the crest. There was an odd familiarity to the way the top of the huge slab seemed to form irregular steps, three up and one down. He climbed the short distance and felt across the stone, walking along it. Despite the weathering of centuries he could still feel four joined columns. He glanced up at the step-like top of the stone, towering over his head like a huge lean-to. Fingers. We'll shelter in Artur Hawkwing's hand. Maybe some of his justice is left here.

hi moʊʃən fəɹ ɛɡwin tə dʒɔɪn hɪm. ʃi dɪd nɑt muv, soʊ hi slɪd bæk daʊn tə ðə beɪs ə ðə hɪl ən toʊld əɹ wʌɾ i hæd faʊnd.

He motioned for Egwene to join him. She did not move, so he slid back down to the base of the hill and told her what he had found.

ɛɡwin pɪɹɾ ʌp ðə hɪl wɪð əɹ hɛd pʊʃt fɔɹwɝd. "haʊ kən jə si ɛniθɪŋ?" ʃi æskt.

Egwene peered up the hill with her head pushed forward. "How can you see anything?" she asked.

pɛɹɪn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ðən ʃʌɾ ɪt. hi lɪkt ɪz lɪps əz i lʊkt ɝaʊnd, fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɹɪli əwɛɹ ʌv wʌɾ i wɑz siɪŋ. ðə sʌn wɑz daʊn. ɔl ðə weɪ daʊn, naʊ, ən klaʊdz hɪd ðə fʊl mun, bʌɾ ɪt stɪl sim laɪk ðə dip pɝpəl fɹɪnʒɪz ə twaɪlaɪt tə hɪm. "aɪ fɛl ðə ɹɑk," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "ðæts wʌɾ ɪts tə bi. ðeɪ woʊn bi eɪbəl tə pɪk əs aʊɾ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ɪɾ ivən ɪf ðeɪ kʌm ðɪs fɑɹ." hi tʊk bɛləz bɹaɪɾəl tə liɾ əɹ tə ðə ʃɛltɝ ə ðə hænd. hi kəd fil ɛɡwinz aɪz ɑn ɪz bæk.

Perrin opened his mouth, then shut it. He licked his lips as he looked around, for the first time really aware of what he was seeing. The sun was down. All the way down, now, and clouds hid the full moon, but it still seemed like the deep purple fringes of twilight to him. "I felt the rock," he said finally. "That's what it has to be. They won't be able to pick us out against the shadow of it even if they come this far." He took Bela's bridle to lead her to the shelter of the hand. He could feel Egwene's eyes on his back.

əz i wɑz hɛlpɪŋ əɹ daʊn fɹəm ðə sæɾəl, ðə naɪt bɹoʊk aʊɾ ɪn ʃaʊts bæk təwɔɹd ðə pul. ʃi leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn pɛɹɪnz ɑɹm, ən i hɝɾ əɹ ənspoʊkən kwɛstʃən.

As he was helping her down from the saddle, the night broke out in shouts back toward the pool. She laid a hand on Perrin's arm, and he heard her unspoken question.

"ðə mɛn sɔ wɪnd," hi sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli. ɪt wɑz dɪfəkəl tə pɪk aʊt ðə minɪŋ ə ðə wʊlvz' θɔts. sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt faɪɝ. "ðeɪ hæv tɔɹtʃɪz." hi pɹɛst əɹ daʊn ət ðə beɪs ə ðə fɪŋɡɝz ən kɹaʊtʃt bɪsaɪd hɝ. "ðeɪɹ bɹeɪkɪŋ ʌp ɪndə pɑɹɾiz tə sɝtʃ. soʊ mɛni ʌv ðɛm, ən ðə wʊlvz ɑɹ ɔl hɝt." hi tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɪz vɔɪs hɑɹɾiɝ. "bʌt dæpəl ən ði ʌðɝz ʃəd bi eɪbəl tə kip aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ weɪ, ivən ɪnʒɝd, ən ðeɪ doʊn ɪkspɛkt ʌs. pipəl doʊn si wʌt ðeɪ doʊn ɪkspɛkt. ðəl ɡɪv ʌp sun ɪnʌf ən meɪk kæmp." ɛlaɪəs wɑz wɪð ðə wʊlvz, ən wəd nɑt liv əm waɪl ðeɪ wɝ hʌntəd. soʊ mɛni ɹaɪɾɝz. soʊ pɝsɪstənt. waɪ soʊ pɝsɪstənt?

"The men saw Wind," he said reluctantly. It was difficult to pick out the meaning of the wolves' thoughts. Something about fire. "They have torches." He pressed her down at the base of the fingers and crouched beside her. "They're breaking up into parties to search. So many of them, and the wolves are all hurt." He tried to make his voice heartier. "But Dapple and the others should be able to keep out of their way, even injured, and they don't expect us. People don't see what they don't expect. They'll give up soon enough and make camp." Elyas was with the wolves, and would not leave them while they were hunted. So many riders. So persistent. Why so persistent?

hi sɔ ɛɡwin nɑd, bʌɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk ʃi dɪd nɑt ɹilaɪz ɪt. "wil bi ɔl ɹaɪt, pɛɹɪn."

He saw Egwene nod, but in the dark she did not realize it. "We'll be all right, Perrin."

laɪt, hi θɔt wʌndɝɪŋli, ʃiz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kʌmfɝt mi.

Light, he thought wonderingly, she's trying to comfort me.

ðə ʃaʊts wɛn ɑn ən ɑn. smɔl nɑts ə tɔɹtʃɪz muvd ɪn ðə dɪstəns, flɪkɝɪŋ pɔɪns ə laɪɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs.

The shouts went on and on. Small knots of torches moved in the distance, flickering points of light in the darkness.

"pɛɹɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd sɔfli, "wɪl jə dæns wɪð mi ət sʌndeɪ? ɪf wɝ hoʊm baɪ ðɛn?"

"Perrin," Egwene said softly, "will you dance with me at Sunday? If we're home by then?"

hɪz ʃoʊldɝz ʃʊk. hi meɪd noʊ saʊnd, ən i dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪf i wɑz læfɪŋ əɹ kɹaɪɪŋ. "aɪ wɪl. aɪ pɹɑməs." əɡɛnst ɪz wɪl ɪz hænz taɪɾənd ɑn ði æks, ɹimaɪndɪŋ ɪm ðəɾ i stɪl hɛld ɪt. hɪz vɔɪs dʒɹɑp tə ə wɪspɝ. "aɪ pɹɑməs," hi sɛɾ əɡɛn, ən hoʊpt.

His shoulders shook. He made no sound, and he did not know if he was laughing or crying. "I will. I promise." Against his will his hands tightened on the axe, reminding him that he still held it. His voice dropped to a whisper. "I promise," he said again, and hoped.

ɡɹups ə tɔɹtʃ-kæɹiɪŋ mɛn naʊ ɹoʊd θɹu ðə hɪlz, bʌntʃəz ə tɛn əɹ twɛlv. pɛɹɪn kəd nɑt tɛl haʊ mɛni ɡɹups ðəɹ wɝ. səmtaɪmz θɹi əɹ fɔɹ wɝ ɪn saɪɾ ət wʌns, kɔɹɾɝɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ. ðeɪ kəntɪnjud tə ʃaʊt tə wʌn ənʌðɝ, ən səmtaɪmz ðəɹ wɝ skɹimz ɪn ðə naɪt, ðə skɹimz ə hɔɹsəz, ðə skɹimz ə mɛn.

Groups of torch-carrying men now rode through the hills, bunches of ten or twelve. Perrin could not tell how many groups there were. Sometimes three or four were in sight at once, quartering back and forth. They continued to shout to one another, and sometimes there were screams in the night, the screams of horses, the screams of men.

hi sɔ ɪɾ ɔl fɹəm mɔɹ ðən wʌn væntədʒ. hi kɹaʊtʃt ɑn ðə hɪlsaɪd wɪð ɛɡwin, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə tɔɹtʃɪz muv θɹu ðə dɑɹknəs laɪk faɪɝəfliz, ən ɪn ɪz maɪn i ɹæn ɪn ðə naɪt wɪð dæpəl, ən wɪnd, ən hɑpɝ. ðə wʊlvz hæd bɪn tu hɝt baɪ ðə ɹeɪvənz tə ɹʌn fɑɹ əɹ fæst, soʊ ðeɪ ɪntɛndəd tə dʒɹaɪv ðə mɛn aʊɾ ə ðə dɑɹknəs, dʒɹaɪv əm tə ðə ʃɛltɝ ə ðɛɹ faɪɝz. mɛn ɔlweɪz sɔt ðə seɪfti ʌv faɪɝz ɪn ði ɛnd, wən wʊlvz ɹoʊm ðə naɪt. səm ə ðə maʊntəd mɛn lɛd stʃɹɪŋz ə hɔɹsəz wɪθaʊt ɹaɪɾɝz; ðeɪ wɪniɾ ən ɹɪɹd wɪð waɪd, ɹoʊlɪŋ aɪz wən ðə ɡɹeɪ ʃeɪps dɑɹɾɪd əmʌŋ ðɛm, skɹimɪŋ ən pʊlɪŋ ðɛɹ lɛd ɹoʊps fɹəm ðə hænz ə ðə mɛn u hɛl ðɛm, skæɾɝɪŋ ɪn ɔl dɝɛkʃənz əz fæst əz ðeɪ kəd ɹʌn. hɔɹsəz wɪð mɛn ɑn ðɛɹ bæks skɹimd, tu, wən ɡɹeɪ ʃædoʊz flæʃt aʊɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wɪð hæmstʃɹɪŋɪŋ fæŋz, ən səmtaɪmz ðɛɹ ɹaɪɾɝz skɹimd əz wɛl, dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ dʒɔz tɔɹ aʊt ðɛɹ θɹoʊts. ɛlaɪəs wɑz aʊt ðɛɹ, ɔlsoʊ, mɔɹ dɪmli sɛnst, stɔkɪŋ ðə naɪt wɪð ɪz lɔŋ naɪf, ə tu-lɛɡəd wʊlf wɪð wʌn ʃɑɹp stil tuθ. ðə ʃaʊts bɪkeɪm kɝsɪz mɔɹ ɔfən ðən nɑt, bʌt ðə sɝtʃɝz ɹəfjuz tə ɡɪv ʌp.

He saw it all from more than one vantage. He crouched on the hillside with Egwene, watching the torches move through the darkness like fireflies, and in his mind he ran in the night with Dapple, and Wind, and Hopper. The wolves had been too hurt by the ravens to run far or fast, so they intended to drive the men out of the darkness, drive them to the shelter of their fires. Men always sought the safety of fires in the end, when wolves roamed the night. Some of the mounted men led strings of horses without riders; they whinnied and reared with wide, rolling eyes when the gray shapes darted among them, screaming and pulling their lead ropes from the hands of the men who held them, scattering in all directions as fast as they could run. Horses with men on their backs screamed, too, when gray shadows flashed out of the dark with hamstringing fangs, and sometimes their riders screamed as well, just before jaws tore out their throats. Elyas was out there, also, more dimly sensed, stalking the night with his long knife, a two-legged wolf with one sharp steel tooth. The shouts became curses more often than not, but the searchers refused to give up.

əbɹʌpli pɛɹɪn ɹilaɪz ðət ðə mɛn wɪð tɔɹtʃɪz wɝ fɑloʊɪŋ ə pæɾɝn. itʃ taɪm səm ə ðə pɑɹɾiz keɪm ɪn vju, wʌn ə ðɛm, ət list, wɑz kloʊsɝ tə ðə hɪlsaɪd wɛɹ i ən ɛɡwin wɝ haɪɾɪŋ. ɛlaɪəs hæd sɛd tə haɪd, bʌt. . . . wʌɾ ɪf wi ɹʌn? meɪbi wi kəd haɪɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk, ɪf wi kip muvɪŋ. meɪbi. ɪts tə bi dɑɹk ɪnʌf fəɹ ðæt.

Abruptly Perrin realized that the men with torches were following a pattern. Each time some of the parties came in view, one of them, at least, was closer to the hillside where he and Egwene were hiding. Elyas had said to hide, but. . . . What if we run? Maybe we could hide in the dark, if we keep moving. Maybe. It has to be dark enough for that.

hi tɝn tə ɛɡwin, bʌɾ əz i dɪd ðə dɪsɪʒən wɑz teɪkən əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. bʌntʃt tɔɹtʃɪz, ə dʌzən ə ðɛm, keɪm ɝaʊn ðə beɪs ə ðə hɪl, weɪvɝɪŋ wɪð ðə tʃɹɑɾ ə ðə hɔɹsəz. lænsəhɛdz ɡlimd ɪn ðə tɔɹtʃlaɪt. hi fɹoʊz, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz bɹɛθ, hænz taɪɾənɪŋ ɑn ɪz æks hæft.

He turned to Egwene, but as he did the decision was taken away from him. Bunched torches, a dozen of them, came around the base of the hill, wavering with the trot of the horses. Lanceheads gleamed in the torchlight. He froze, holding his breath, hands tightening on his axe haft.

ðə hɔɹsmən ɹoʊd pæs ðə hɪl, bʌt wʌn ə ðə mɛn ʃaʊɾəd, ən ðə tɔɹtʃɪz swʌŋ bæk. hi θɔt dɛspɝətli, sikɪŋ fəɹ ə weɪ tə ɡoʊ. bʌɾ əz sun əz ðeɪ muv ðeɪ wəd bi sin, ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn, ən wʌns ðeɪ wɝ mɑɹk ðeɪ wəɾ əv noʊ tʃæns, nɑɾ ivən wɪð ðə dɑɹknəs tə hɛlp.

The horsemen rode past the hill, but one of the men shouted, and the torches swung back. He thought desperately, seeking for a way to go. But as soon as they moved they would be seen, if they had not already been, and once they were marked they would have no chance, not even with the darkness to help.

ðə hɔɹsmən dʒɹu ʌp ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə hɪl, itʃ mæn hoʊldɪŋ ə tɔɹtʃ ɪn wʌn hæn ən ə lɔŋ læns ɪn ði ʌðɝ, ɡaɪɾɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs baɪ ðə pɹɛʃɝ ə hɪz niz. baɪ ðə laɪɾ ə ðə tɔɹtʃɪz pɛɹɪn kəd si ðə waɪt kloʊks ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. ðeɪ hɛl ðə tɔɹtʃɪz haɪ ən lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, piɹɪŋ ʌp ət ðə dip ʃædoʊz ʌndɝ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋz fɪŋɡɝz.

The horsemen drew up at the foot of the hill, each man holding a torch in one hand and a long lance in the other, guiding his horse by the pressure of his knees. By the light of the torches Perrin could see the white cloaks of the Children of the Light. They held the torches high and leaned forward in their saddles, peering up at the deep shadows under Artur Hawkwing's fingers.

"ðɛɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ʌp ðɛɹ," wʌn ə ðɛm sɛd. hɪz vɔɪs wɑz tu laʊd, əz ɪf i wɑz əfɹeɪɾ ʌv wʌt leɪ aʊtsaɪd ðə laɪɾ ə hɪz tɔɹtʃ. "aɪ toʊl jə sʌmbɑɾi kəd haɪɾ ɪn ðæt. ɪzən ðəɾ ə hɔɹs?"

"There is something up there," one of them said. His voice was too loud, as if he was afraid of what lay outside the light of his torch. "I told you somebody could hide in that. Isn't that a horse?"

ɛɡwin leɪɾ ə hæn ɑn pɛɹɪnz ɑɹm; hɝ aɪz wɝ bɪɡ ɪn ðə dɑɹk. hɝ saɪlən kwɛstʃən pleɪn dɪspaɪt ðə ʃædoʊ haɪɾɪŋ əɹ fitʃɝz. wʌt tə du? ɛlaɪəs ən ðə wʊlvz stɪl hʌntəd θɹu ðə naɪt. ðə hɔɹsəz bɪloʊ ʃɪftəd ðɛɹ fit nɝvəsli. ɪf wi ɹʌn naʊ, ðəl tʃeɪs əs daʊn.

Egwene laid a hand on Perrin's arm; her eyes were big in the dark. Her silent question plain despite the shadow hiding her features. What to do? Elyas and the wolves still hunted through the night. The horses below shifted their feet nervously. If we run now, they'll chase us down.

wʌn ə ðə waɪtkloʊks stɛpt ɪz hɔɹs fɔɹwɝɾ ən ʃaʊɾəd ʌp ðə hɪl. "ɪf jə kən ʌndɝstæn hjumən spitʃ, kʌm daʊn ən sɝɛndɝ. jəl nɑt bi hɑɹmd ɪf jə wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt. ɪf jə doʊn sɝɛndɝ, jəl ɔl bi kɪld. juv wʌn mɪnut." ðə lænsɪz loʊɝd, lɔŋ stil hɛdz bɹaɪt wɪð tɔɹtʃlaɪt.

One of the Whitecloaks stepped his horse forward and shouted up the hill. "If you can understand human speech, come down and surrender. You'll not be harmed if you walk in the Light. If you don't surrender, you will all be killed. You have one minute." The lances lowered, long steel heads bright with torchlight.

"pɛɹɪn," ɛɡwin wɪspɝd, "wi kæn aʊtʃɹʌn ðɛm. ɪf wi doʊnt ɡɪv ʌp, ðəl kɪl ʌs. pɛɹɪn?"

"Perrin," Egwene whispered, "we can't outrun them. If we don't give up, they'll kill us. Perrin?"

ɛlaɪəs ən ðə wʊlvz wɝ stɪl fɹi. ənʌðɝ dɪstənt, bʌbəlɪŋ skɹim mɑɹkt ə waɪtkloʊk u hæd hʌntəd dæpəl tu kloʊsli. ɪf wi ɹʌn. . . . ɛɡwin wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə tɛl əɹ wʌt tə du. ɪf wi ɹʌn. . . . hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd wɛɹəli ən stʊɾ ʌp laɪk ə mæn ɪn ə tʃɹæns, stʌmbəlɪŋ daʊn ðə hɪl təwɔɹd ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. hi hɝɾ ɛɡwin saɪ ən fɑloʊ hɪm, hɝ fit dʒɹæɡɪŋ ɹɪlʌktənli. waɪ ɑɹ ðə waɪtkloʊks soʊ pɝsɪstənt, əz ɪf ðeɪ heɪt wʊlvz wɪð ə pæʃən? waɪ də ðeɪ smɛl ɹɔŋ? hi ɔlmoʊs θɔɾ i kəd smɛl ðə ɹɔŋɡnəs hɪmsɛlf, wən ðə wɪnd ɡʌstɪd fɹəm ðə ɹaɪɾɝz.

Elyas and the wolves were still free. Another distant, bubbling scream marked a Whitecloak who had hunted Dapple too closely. If we run. . . . Egwene was looking at him, waiting for him to tell her what to do. If we run. . . . He shook his head wearily and stood up like a man in a trance, stumbling down the hill toward the Children of the Light. He heard Egwene sigh and follow him, her feet dragging reluctantly. Why are the Whitecloaks so persistent, as if they hate wolves with a passion? Why do they smell wrong? He almost thought he could smell the wrongness himself, when the wind gusted from the riders.

"dʒɹɑp ðəɾ æks," ðə liɾɝ bɑɹkt.

"Drop that axe," the leader barked.

pɛɹɪn stʌmbəl təwɔɹd hɪm, ɹɪŋkəlɪŋ ɪz noʊz tə ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðə smɛl i θɔɾ i smɛlt.

Perrin stumbled toward him, wrinkling his nose to get rid of the smell he thought he smelt.

"dʒɹɑp ɪt, bʌmpkɪn!" ðə liɾɝz læns ʃɪftəd təwɔɹd pɛɹɪnz tʃɛst.

"Drop it, bumpkin!" The leader's lance shifted toward Perrin's chest.

fəɹ ə moʊmən i stɛɹɾ ət ðə lænsəhɛd, ɪnʌf ʃɑɹp stil tə ɡoʊ kəmplitli θɹu hɪm, ən əbɹʌpli hi ʃaʊɾəd, "noʊ!" ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ət ðə hɔɹsmən i ʃaʊɾəd.

For a moment he stared at the lancehead, enough sharp steel to go completely through him, and abruptly he shouted, "No!" It was not at the horseman he shouted.
