aʊɾ ə ðə naɪt hɑpɝ keɪm, ən pɛɹɪn wɑz wʌn wɪð ðə wʊlf. hɑpɝ, ðə kʌb u hæd wɑtʃt ði iɡəlz sɔɹ, ən wɑntəd soʊ bædli tə flaɪ θɹu ðə skaɪ əz ði iɡəlz dɪd. ðə kʌb u hɑpt ən dʒʌmpt ən lɛpt əntɪl i kəd lip haɪɝ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ wʊlf, ən u nɛvɝ lɔs ðə kʌbz jɝnɪŋ tə sɔɹ θɹu ðə skaɪ. aʊɾ ə ðə naɪt hɑpɝ keɪm ən lɛf ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn ə lip, sɔɹɪŋ laɪk ði iɡəlz. ðə waɪtkloʊks hæɾ oʊnli ə moʊmən tə bɪɡɪn kɝsɪŋ bɪfɔɹ hɑpɝz dʒɔz kloʊzd ɑn ðə θɹoʊɾ ə ðə mæn wɪð ɪz læns lɛvəld ət pɛɹɪn. ðə bɪɡ wʊlfs moʊmɛntəm kæɹiɾ əm boʊθ ɔf ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə hɔɹs. pɛɹɪn fɛl ðə θɹoʊt kɹʌʃɪŋ, teɪstəd ðə blʌd.

Out of the night Hopper came, and Perrin was one with the wolf. Hopper, the cub who had watched the eagles soar, and wanted so badly to fly through the sky as the eagles did. The cub who hopped and jumped and leaped until he could leap higher than any other wolf, and who never lost the cub's yearning to soar through the sky. Out of the night Hopper came and left the ground in a leap, soaring like the eagles. The Whitecloaks had only a moment to begin cursing before Hopper's jaws closed on the throat of the man with his lance leveled at Perrin. The big wolf's momentum carried them both off the other side of the horse. Perrin felt the throat crushing, tasted the blood.

hɑpɝ lændəd laɪtli, ɔlɹɛɾi əpɑɹt fɹəm ðə mæn i hæd kɪld. blʌd mæɾɪd ɪz fɝ, hɪz oʊn blʌɾ ən ðəɾ ʌv ʌðɝz. ə ɡæʃ daʊn ɪz feɪs kɹɔs ði ɛmpti sɑkət wɛɹ ɪz lɛft aɪ hæd bɪn. hɪz ɡʊɾ aɪ mɛt pɛɹɪnz tu fəɹ dʒʌst ən ɪnstənt. ɹʌn, bɹʌðɝ! hi wɝl tə lip əɡɛn, tə sɔɹ wʌn læs taɪm, ən ə læns pɪn ɪm tə ði ɝθ. ə sɛkən lɛŋθ ə stil θɹʌs θɹu hɪz ɹɪbz, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊn ʌndɝ hɪm. kɪkɪŋ, hi snæpt ət ðə ʃæfs ðət hɛl hɪm. tə sɔɹ.

Hopper landed lightly, already apart from the man he had killed. Blood matted his fur, his own blood and that of others. A gash down his face crossed the empty socket where his left eye had been. His good eye met Perrin's two for just an instant. Run, brother! He whirled to leap again, to soar one last time, and a lance pinned him to the earth. A second length of steel thrust through his ribs, driving into the ground under him. Kicking, he snapped at the shafts that held him. To soar.

peɪn fɪl pɛɹɪn, ən i skɹimd, ə wɝdləs skɹim ðət hæd sʌmθɪŋ ʌv ə wʊlfs kɹaɪ ɪn ɪt. wɪθaʊt θɪŋkɪŋ i lɛp fɔɹwɝd, stɪl skɹimɪŋ. ɔl θɔt wɑz ɡɔn. ðə hɔɹsmən hæd bʌntʃt tu mʌtʃ tə bi eɪbəl tə juz ðɛɹ lænsɪz, ən ði æks wɑz ə fɛðɝ ɪn ɪz hænz, wʌn hjudʒ wʊlfs tuθ ə stil. sʌmθɪŋ kɹæʃt ɪndə hɪz hɛd, ən əz i fɛl, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪf ɪt wɑz hɑpɝ əɹ hɪmsɛlf u daɪd.

Pain filled Perrin, and he screamed, a wordless scream that had something of a wolf's cry in it. Without thinking he leaped forward, still screaming. All thought was gone. The horsemen had bunched too much to be able to use their lances, and the axe was a feather in his hands, one huge wolf's tooth of steel. Something crashed into his head, and as he fell, he did not know if it was Hopper or himself who died.

". . . sɔɹ laɪk ði iɡəlz."

". . . soar like the eagles."

mʌmbəlɪŋ, pɛɹɪn oʊpən ɪz aɪz wuzəli. hɪz hɛd hɝt, ən i kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ waɪ. blɪŋkɪŋ əɡɛns ðə laɪt, hi lʊkt ɝaʊnd. ɛɡwin wɑz nilɪŋ ən wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm wɛɹ i leɪ. ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ə skwɛɹ tɛn əz bɪɡ əz ə miɾiəm-saɪzd ɹum ɪn ə fɑɹmhaʊs, wɪð ə ɡɹaʊn klɔθ fəɹ ə flɔɹ. ɔɪl læmps ɑn tɔl stænz, wʌn ɪn itʃ kɔɹnɝ, ɡeɪv ə bɹaɪt laɪt.

Mumbling, Perrin opened his eyes woozily. His head hurt, and he could not remember why. Blinking against the light, he looked around. Egwene was kneeling and watching him where he lay. They were in a square tent as big as a medium-sized room in a farmhouse, with a ground cloth for a floor. Oil lamps on tall stands, one in each corner, gave a bright light.

"θæŋk ðə laɪt, pɛɹɪn," ʃi bɹiðd. "aɪ wɑz əfɹeɪd ðeɪ hæd kɪl ju."

"Thank the Light, Perrin," she breathed. "I was afraid they had killed you."

ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ænsɝɪŋ, hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn siɾəd ɪn ðə loʊn tʃɛɹ ɪn ðə tɛnt. ə dɑɹk-aɪd, ɡɹændfɑðɝli feɪs lʊk bæk ət hɪm, ə feɪs əɾ ɑdz ɪn ɪz maɪnd wɪð ðə waɪt-ænd-ɡoʊl tɑbɝd ðə mæn wɔɹ, ən ðə bɝnɪʃt ɑɹmɝ stʃɹæpt oʊvɝ ɪz pjʊɹ-waɪɾ ʌndɝkoʊt. ɪt simd ə kaɪnli feɪs, blʌf ən dɪɡnəfaɪd, ən sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt fɪt ði ɛləɡən ɔstɛɹɪɾi ʌv ðə tɛns fɝnɪʃɪŋz. ə teɪbəl ən ə foʊldɪŋ bɛd, ə wɑʃstænd wɪð ə pleɪn waɪt beɪsən ən pɪtʃɝ, ə sɪŋɡəl wʊɾən tʃɛst ɪnleɪɾ ɪn sɪmpəl dʒiəmɛtʃɹɪk pæɾɝnz. wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz wʊd, ɪt wɑz pɑlɪʃt tə ə sɑft ɡloʊ, ən ðə mɛɾəl ɡlimd, bʌt nɑt tu bɹaɪtli, ən nʌθɪŋ wɑz ʃoʊi. ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ðə tɛn hæd ðə lʊk ə kɹæfsmənʃɪp, bʌɾ oʊnli sʌmwʌn u hæd wɑtʃt ðə wɝk ə kɹæfsmən - laɪk mæstɝ luhən, əɹ mæstɝ eɪdɑɹ, ðə kæbəntmeɪkɝ - wəd si ɪt.

Instead of answering, he stared at the gray-haired man seated in the lone chair in the tent. A dark-eyed, grandfatherly face looked back at him, a face at odds in his mind with the white-and-gold tabard the man wore, and the burnished armor strapped over his pure-white undercoat. It seemed a kindly face, bluff and dignified, and something about it fit the elegant austerity of the tent's furnishings. A table and a folding bed, a washstand with a plain white basin and pitcher, a single wooden chest inlaid in simple geometric patterns. Where there was wood, it was polished to a soft glow, and the metal gleamed, but not too brightly, and nothing was showy. Everything in the tent had the look of craftsmanship, but only someone who had watched the work of craftsmen - like Master Luhhan, or Master Aydaer, the cabinetmaker - would see it.

fɹaʊnɪŋ, ðə mæn stɝd tu smɔl paɪlz ʌv ɑbʒɛkts ɑn ðə teɪbəl wɪð ə blʌn fɪŋɡɝ. pɛɹɪn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə kɑntɛns ə hɪz pɑkəts ɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz paɪlz, ən ɪz bɛl naɪf. ðə sɪlvɝ kɔɪn mɔɪɹeɪn hæd ɡɪvən ɪm tɑpəld aʊt, ən ðə mæn pʊʃt ɪt bæk θɔtfəli. pɝsɪŋ ɪz lɪps, hi lɛf ðə paɪlz ən lɪftəd pɛɹɪnz æks fɹəm ðə teɪbəl, hɛftɪŋ ɪt. hɪz ətɛnʃən keɪm bæk tə ði ɛmənz fildɝz.

Frowning, the man stirred two small piles of objects on the table with a blunt finger. Perrin recognized the contents of his pockets in one of those piles, and his belt knife. The silver coin Moiraine had given him toppled out, and the man pushed it back thoughtfully. Pursing his lips, he left the piles and lifted Perrin's axe from the table, hefting it. His attention came back to the Emond's Fielders.

pɛɹɪn tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɛɾ ʌp. ʃɑɹp peɪn stæbɪŋ əlɔŋ ɪz ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz tɝn ðə muvmən ɪndə ə flɑp. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm i ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz taɪd, hæn ən fʊt. hɪz aɪz wɛn tə ɛɡwin. ʃi ʃɹʌɡd ɹufəli, ən twɪstəd soʊ ðəɾ i kəd si hɝ bæk. hæf ə dʌzən læʃɪŋz ɹæpt əɹ ɹɪsts ən æŋkəlz, ðə kɔɹdz meɪkɪŋ ɹɪdʒəz ɪn əɹ flɛʃ. ə lɛŋθ ə ɹoʊp ɹæn bɪtwin ðə bɑnz ɝaʊn æŋkəlz ən ɹɪsts, ʃɔɹɾ ɪnʌf tə stɑp əɹ fɹəm stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ tə mɔɹ ðən ə kɹaʊtʃ ɪf ʃi ɡɑt tə hɝ fit.

Perrin tried to get up. Sharp pain stabbing along his arms and legs turned the movement into a flop. For the first time he realized that he was tied, hand and foot. His eyes went to Egwene. She shrugged ruefully, and twisted so that he could see her back. Half a dozen lashings wrapped her wrists and ankles, the cords making ridges in her flesh. A length of rope ran between the bonds around ankles and wrists, short enough to stop her from straightening to more than a crouch if she got to her feet.

pɛɹɪn stɛɹd. ðət ðeɪ wɝ taɪd wɑz ʃɑk ɪnʌf, bʌt ðeɪ wɔɹ ɪnʌf ɹoʊps tə hoʊl hɔɹsəz. wʌt də ðeɪ θɪŋk wi ɑɹ?

Perrin stared. That they were tied was shock enough, but they wore enough ropes to hold horses. What do they think we are?

ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn wɑtʃt ðɛm, kjʊɹiəs ən θɔtfəl, laɪk mæstɝ ælvɪɹ pʌzəlɪŋ aʊɾ ə pɹɑbləm. hi hɛl ði æks əz ɪf i hæd fɝɡɑɾən ɪt.

The gray-haired man watched them, curious and thoughtful, like Master al'Vere puzzling out a problem. He held the axe as if he had forgotten it.

ðə tɛn flæp ʃɪftəɾ əsaɪd, ən ə tɔl mæn stɛpt ɪndə ðə tɛnt. hɪz feɪs wɑz lɔŋ ən ɡɔnt, wɪð aɪz soʊ dipli sɛt ðeɪ sim tə lʊk aʊt fɹəm keɪvz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɛksɛs flɛʃ ɑn hɪm, noʊ fæɾ əɾ ɔl; hɪz skɪn wɑz pʊl taɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə mʌsəl ən boʊn bɪniθ.

The tent flap shifted aside, and a tall man stepped into the tent. His face was long and gaunt, with eyes so deeply set they seemed to look out from caves. There was no excess flesh on him, no fat at all; his skin was pulled tight over the muscle and bone beneath.

pɛɹɪn hæɾ ə ɡlɪmps ə naɪɾ aʊtsaɪd, ən kæmpfaɪɝz, ən tu waɪt-kloʊkt ɡɑɹdz ət ði ɛntʃɹəns ə ðə tɛnt, ðən ðə flæp fɛl bæk ɪndə pleɪs. əz sun əz ðə nukʌmɝ wɑz ɪndə ðə tɛnt, hi stɑpt, stændɪŋ əz ɹɪdʒəɾ əz ən aɪɝn ɹɑd, stɛɹɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛɾ ə hɪm ət ðə fɑɹ wɔl ə ðə tɛnt. hɪz pleɪt-ænd-meɪl ɑɹmɝ ɡlim laɪk sɪlvɝ əɡɛnst ɪz snoʊi kloʊk ən ʌndɝkoʊt.

Perrin had a glimpse of night outside, and campfires, and two white-cloaked guards at the entrance of the tent, then the flap fell back into place. As soon as the newcomer was into the tent, he stopped, standing as rigid as an iron rod, staring straight ahead of him at the far wall of the tent. His plate-and-mail armor gleamed like silver against his snowy cloak and undercoat.

"maɪ lɔɹd kæptən." hɪz vɔɪs wɑz əz hɑɹɾ əz ɪz pɑstʃɝ, ən ɡɹeɪɾɪŋ, bʌt sʌmhaʊ flæt, wɪθaʊɾ ɪkspɹɛʃən.

"My Lord Captain." His voice was as hard as his posture, and grating, but somehow flat, without expression.

ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn meɪɾ ə kæʒəwəl dʒɛstʃɝ. "bi ət jəɹ iz, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ. juv tæliɾ əɹ kɑsts fəɹ ðɪs . . . ɪnkaʊntɝ?"

The gray-haired man made a casual gesture. "Be at your ease, Child Byar. You have tallied our costs for this . . . encounter?"

ðə tɔl mæn muvd ɪz fiɾ əpɑɹt, bʌɾ ʌðɝ ðən ðət pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt si ɛniθɪŋ iz əbaʊɾ ɪz stæns. "naɪn mɛn dɛd, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən, ən twɛnti-θɹi ɪnʒɝd, sɛvən sɪɹiəsli. ɔl kən ɹaɪd, ðoʊ. θɝɾi hɔɹsəz hæd tə bi pʊt daʊn. ðeɪ wɝ hæmstʃɹəŋ!" hi ɛmfəsaɪz ðəɾ ɪn ɪz ɪmoʊʃənləs vɔɪs, əz ɪf wʌt hæd hæpən tə ðə hɔɹsəz wɝ wɝs ðən ðə dɛθs ən ɪnʒɝiz tə mɛn. "mɛni ʌv ðə ɹimaʊns ɑɹ skæɾɝd. wi meɪ faɪn səm ət deɪbɹeɪk, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən, bʌt wɪð wʊlvz tə sɛn əm ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ, ɪɾəl teɪk deɪz tə ɡæðɝ əm ɔl. ðə mɛn u wɝ səpoʊz tə bi wɑtʃɪŋ əm əv bɪn əsaɪn tə naɪt ɡɑɹɾ əntɪl wi ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn."

The tall man moved his feet apart, but other than that Perrin did not see anything ease about his stance. "Nine men dead, my Lord Captain, and twenty-three injured, seven seriously. All can ride, though. Thirty horses had to be put down. They were hamstrung!" He emphasized that in his emotionless voice, as if what had happened to the horses were worse than the deaths and injuries to men. "Many of the remounts are scattered. We may find some at daybreak, my Lord Captain, but with wolves to send them on their way, it will take days to gather them all. The men who were supposed to be watching them have been assigned to night guard until we reach Caemlyn."

"wi də nɑɾ əv deɪz, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ," ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn sɛd maɪldli. "wi ɹaɪɾ ət dɔn. nʌθɪŋ kən tʃeɪnʒ ðæt. wi mʌs bi ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ɪn taɪm, jɛs?"

"We do not have days, Child Byar," the gray-haired man said mildly. "We ride at dawn. Nothing can change that. We must be in Caemlyn in time, yes?"

"æz jə kəmænd, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən."

"As you command, my Lord Captain."

ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn ɡlænst ət pɛɹɪn ən ɛɡwin, ðən əweɪ əɡɛn. "ænd wʌɾ əv wi tə ʃoʊ fəɹ ɪt, əsaɪd fɹəm ðiz tu jʌŋɡəlɪŋz?"

The gray-haired man glanced at Perrin and Egwene, then away again. "And what have we to show for it, aside from these two younglings?"

baɪɑɝ dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ ən hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "aɪ hæv hæd ðə wʊlf ðət wɑz wɪð ðɪs lɑt skɪnd, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən. ðə haɪd ʃəd meɪk ə faɪn ɹʌɡ fəɹ maɪ lɔɹd kæptənz tɛnt."

Byar drew a deep breath and hesitated. "I have had the wolf that was with this lot skinned, my Lord Captain. The hide should make a fine rug for my Lord Captain's tent."

hɑpɝ! nɑɾ ivən ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ, pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld ən stʃɹʌɡəld əɡɛnst ɪz bɑnz. ðə ɹoʊps dʌɡ ɪndə hɪz skɪn - hɪz ɹɪsts bɪkeɪm slɪpɝi wɪð blʌd - bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ɡɪv.

Hopper! Not even realizing what he was doing, Perrin growled and struggled against his bonds. The ropes dug into his skin - his wrists became slippery with blood - but they did not give.

fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm baɪɑɝ lʊkt ət ðə pɹɪznɝz. ɛɡwin stɑɹɾəd bæk fɹəm hɪm. hɪz feɪs wɑz əz ɪkspɹɛʃənləs əz ɪz vɔɪs, bʌɾ ə kɹuəl laɪt bɝn ɪn ɪz sʌŋkən aɪz, əz ʃʊɹli əz fleɪmz bɝn ɪn bælzəmənz. baɪɑɝ heɪɾəd əm əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɛnəmiz ə lɔŋ jɪɹz ɪnstɛɾ ə pipəl nɛvɝ sin bɪfɔɹ tənaɪt.

For the first time Byar looked at the prisoners. Egwene started back from him. His face was as expressionless as his voice, but a cruel light burned in his sunken eyes, as surely as flames burned in Ba'alzamon's. Byar hated them as if they were enemies of long years instead of people never seen before tonight.

pɛɹɪn stɛɹd bæk dɪfaɪənli. hɪz maʊθ kɝld ɪndə ə taɪt smaɪl ət ðə θɔɾ ə hɪz tiθ miɾɪŋ ɪn ðə mænz θɹoʊt.

Perrin stared back defiantly. His mouth curled into a tight smile at the thought of his teeth meeting in the man's throat.

əbɹʌpli hɪz smaɪl feɪɾəd, ən i ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf. maɪ tiθ? ɪm ə mæn, nɑɾ ə wʊlf! laɪt, ðəɹ əz tə bi ən ɛn tə ðɪs! bʌɾ i stɪl mɛt baɪɑɝz ɡlɛɹ, heɪt fəɹ heɪt.

Abruptly his smile faded, and he shook himself. My teeth? I'm a man, not a wolf! Light, there has to be an end to this! But he still met Byar's glare, hate for hate.

"aɪ də nɑt kɛɹ əbaʊt wʊlf-haɪd ɹʌɡz, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ." ðə ɹibjuk ɪn ðə lɔɹd kæptənz vɔɪs wɑz dʒɛntəl, bʌt baɪɑɝz bæk snæpt ɹɪdʒəɾ əɡɛn, hɪz aɪz lɑkɪŋ tə ðə wɔl ə ðə tɛnt. "ju wɝ ɹipɔɹɾɪŋ ɑn wʌt wi ətʃiv ðɪs naɪt, noʊ? ɪf wi ətʃivd ɛniθɪŋ."

"I do not care about wolf-hide rugs, Child Byar." The rebuke in the Lord Captain's voice was gentle, but Byar's back snapped rigid again, his eyes locking to the wall of the tent. "You were reporting on what we achieved this night, no? If we achieved anything."

lɔɹd kæptənz vɔɪs wɑz dʒɛntəl, bʌt baɪɑɝz bæk snæpt ɹɪdʒəɾ əɡɛn, hɪz aɪz lɑkɪŋ tə ðə wɔl ə ðə tɛnt. "ju wɝ ɹipɔɹɾɪŋ ɑn wʌt wi ətʃiv ðɪs naɪt, noʊ? ɪf wi ətʃivd ɛniθɪŋ."

Lord Captain's voice was gentle, but Byar's back snapped rigid again, his eyes locking to the wall of the tent. "You were reporting on what we achieved this night, no? If we achieved anything."

"aɪ wəɾ ɛstəmeɪt ðə pæk ðəɾ ətækt əs ət fɪfti bists əɹ mɔɹ, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən. ʌv ðæt, wi kɪld ət lis twɛnti, pɝhæps θɝɾi. aɪ dɪd nɑt kənsɪɾɝ ɪt wɝθ ðə ɹɪsk ə luzɪŋ mɔɹ hɔɹsəz tə hæv ðə kɑɹkəsɪz bɹɔɾ ɪn tənaɪt. ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ əl əv əm ɡæðɝɾ ən bɝnd, ðoʊz ðəɾ ɑɹən dʒɹæɡd ɔf ɪn ðə dɑɹk. bɪsaɪdz ðiz tu, ðəɹ wɝ ət list ə dʌzən ʌðɝ mɛn. aɪ bɪliv wi dɪspoʊzd ə fɔɹ əɹ faɪv, bʌɾ ɪts ənlaɪkli wɪl faɪn ɛni bɑɾiz, ɡɪvən ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnz' pɹəpɛnsɪɾi fəɹ kæɹiɪŋ əweɪ ðɛɹ dɛd tə haɪd ðɛɹ lɔsəz. ðɪs simz tə hæv bɪn ə koʊɔɹɾəneɪtɪd æmbʊʃ, bʌt ðət ɹeɪzəz ðə kwɛstʃən ʌv. . . ."

"I would estimate the pack that attacked us at fifty beasts or more, my Lord Captain. Of that, we killed at least twenty, perhaps thirty. I did not consider it worth the risk of losing more horses to have the carcasses brought in tonight. In the morning I will have them gathered and burned, those that aren't dragged off in the dark. Besides these two, there were at least a dozen other men. I believe we disposed of four or five, but it is unlikely we will find any bodies, given the Darkfriends' propensity for carrying away their dead to hide their losses. This seems to have been a coordinated ambush, but that raises the question of. . . ."

pɛɹɪnz θɹoʊt taɪɾənd əz ðə ɡɔn mæn wɛn ɑn. ɛlaɪəs? kɔʃəsli, ɹɪlʌktənli, hi fɛl fəɹ ɛlaɪəs, fəɹ ðə wʊlvz . . . ən faʊnd nʌθɪŋ. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf i hæd nɛvɝ bɪn eɪbəl tə fil ə wʊlfs maɪnd. iðɝ ðəɹ dɛd, əɹ ðeɪv əbændən ju. hi wɑntəd tə læf, ə bɪɾɝ læf. ət læst i hæd wʌɾ i hæd bɪn wɪʃɪŋ fɔɹ, bʌt ðə pɹaɪs wɑz haɪ.

Perrin's throat tightened as the gaunt man went on. Elyas? Cautiously, reluctantly, he felt for Elyas, for the wolves . . . and found nothing. It was as if he had never been able to feel a wolf's mind. Either they're dead, or they've abandoned you. He wanted to laugh, a bitter laugh. At last he had what he had been wishing for, but the price was high.

ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn dɪd læf, dʒʌs ðɛn, ə ɹɪtʃ, ɹaɪ tʃʌkəl ðət meɪɾ ə ɹɛd spɑt blum ɑn itʃ ə baɪɑɝz tʃiks. "soʊ, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ, ɪts jəɹ kənsɪɾɝd ɛstəmeɪt ðət wi wɝ ətækt ɪn ə plæn æmbʊʃ baɪ ʌpwɝdz ə fɪfti wʊlvz ən bɛɾɝ ðən hæf ə skɔɹ ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz? jɛs? pɝhæps wən juv sin ə fju mɔɹ ækʃənz . . . ."

The gray-haired man did laugh, just then, a rich, wry chuckle that made a red spot bloom on each of Byar's cheeks. "So, Child Byar, it is your considered estimate that we were attacked in a planned ambush by upwards of fifty wolves and better than half a score of Darkfriends? Yes? Perhaps when you've seen a few more actions . . . ."

"bʌt, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən bɔɹnhəld . . . ."

"But, my Lord Captain Bornhald . . . ."

"aɪ wəd seɪ sɪks əɹ eɪt wʊlvz, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ, ən pɝhæps noʊ ʌðɝ hjumənz ðən ðiz tu. juv ðə tʃɹu zil, bʌt noʊ ɪkspɪɹiəns aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾiz. ɪts ə dɪfɹən θɪŋ, bɹɪŋɪŋ ðə laɪt, wən stʃɹits ən haʊsəz ɑɹ fɑɹ dɪstənt. wʊlvz əv ə weɪ ʌv simɪŋ mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ ɑɹ, ɪn ðə naɪt - ən mɛn, ɔlsoʊ. sɪks əɹ eɪɾ ət moʊst, aɪ θɪŋk." baɪɑɝz flʌʃ dipən sloʊli. "aɪ ɔlsoʊ səspɛk ðeɪ wɝ hɪɹ fəɹ ðə seɪm ɹizən wi ɑɹ: ði oʊnli izi wɔɾɝ fəɹ ət list ə deɪ ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən. ə mʌtʃ sɪmpəlɝ ɛkspləneɪʃən ðən spaɪz əɹ tʃɹeɪɾɝz wɪðɪn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən, ən ðə sɪmpləst ɛkspləneɪʃən ɪz juʒəwəli ðə tʃɹuɪst. jəl lɝn, wɪð ɪkspɪɹiəns."

"I would say six or eight wolves, Child Byar, and perhaps no other humans than these two. You have the true zeal, but no experience outside the cities. It is a different thing, bringing the Light, when streets and houses are far distant. Wolves have a way of seeming more than they are, in the night - and men, also. Six or eight at most, I think." Byar's flush deepened slowly. "I also suspect they were here for the same reason we are: the only easy water for at least a day in any direction. A much simpler explanation than spies or traitors within the Children, and the simplest explanation is usually the truest. You will learn, with experience."

baɪɑɝz feɪs wɛn dɛθli waɪɾ əz ðə ɡɹændfɑðɝli mæn spoʊk; baɪ kəntʃɹæst, ðə tu spɑts ɪn ɪz hɑloʊ tʃiks dipən fɹəm ɹɛd tə pɝpəl. hi kʌɾ ɪz aɪz təwɔɹd ðə tu pɹɪznɝz fəɹ ən ɪnstənt.

Byar's face went deathly white as the grandfatherly man spoke; by contrast, the two spots in his hollow cheeks deepened from red to purple. He cut his eyes toward the two prisoners for an instant.

hi heɪts əs ivən mɔɹ, naʊ, pɛɹɪn θɔt, fəɹ hɪɹɪŋ ðɪs. bʌt waɪ dɪɾ i heɪɾ əs ɪn ðə fɝs pleɪs?

He hates us even more, now, Perrin thought, for hearing this. But why did he hate us in the first place?

"wʌt dʒju θɪŋk ə ðɪs?" ðə lɔɹd kæptən sɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ʌp pɛɹɪnz æks.

"What do you think of this?" the Lord Captain said, holding up Perrin's axe.

baɪɑɝ lʊkt ə kwɛstʃən əɾ ɪz kəmændɝ ən weɪɾəd fəɹ ən ænsɝɪŋ nɑd bɪfɔɹ i bɹoʊk ɪz ɹɪdʒəd stæns tə teɪk ðə wɛpən. hi hɛftəd ði æks ən ɡeɪv ə sɝpɹaɪzd ɡɹʌnt, ðən wɝld ɪɾ ɪn ə taɪɾ ɑɹk əbʌv ɪz hɛd ðət bɛɹli mɪs ðə tɑp ə ðə tɛnt. hi hændəld ɪɾ əz ʃʊɹli əz ɪf i hæd bɪn bɔɹn wɪð ən æks ɪn ɪz hænz. ə lʊk ʌv ɡɹʌdʒɪŋ ædmɝeɪʃən flɪkɝɾ əkɹɔs ɪz feɪs, bʌt baɪ ðə taɪm i loʊɝd ði æks i wɑz ɪkspɹɛʃənləs wʌns mɔɹ.

Byar looked a question at his commander and waited for an answering nod before he broke his rigid stance to take the weapon. He hefted the axe and gave a surprised grunt, then whirled it in a tight arc above his head that barely missed the top of the tent. He handled it as surely as if he had been born with an axe in his hands. A look of grudging admiration flickered across his face, but by the time he lowered the axe he was expressionless once more.

"ɛksələnli bælənst, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən. pleɪnli meɪd, bʌt baɪ ə vɛɹi ɡʊd wɛpənsmɪθ, pɝhæps ivən ə mæstɝ." hɪz aɪz bɝn dɑɹkli ət ðə pɹɪznɝz. "nɑɾ ə vɪlɪdʒɝz wɛpən, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən. nɔɹ ə fɑɹmɝz."

"Excellently balanced, my Lord Captain. Plainly made, but by a very good weaponsmith, perhaps even a master." His eyes burned darkly at the prisoners. "Not a villager's weapon, my Lord Captain. Nor a farmer's."

"noʊ." ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn tɝn təwɔɹd pɛɹɪn ən ɛɡwin wɪð ə wɪɹi, slaɪtli tʃaɪɾɪŋ smaɪl, ə kaɪnli ɡɹændfɑðɝ u nu hɪz ɡɹæntʃɪlʒɹən hæd bɪn ʌp tə səm mɪstʃəf. "maɪ neɪm ɪz dʒɛəfɹæm bɔɹnhəld," hi toʊl ðɛm. "ju ɑɹ pɛɹɪn, aɪ ʌndɝstænd. bʌt ju, jʌŋ wʊmən, wʌɾ ɪz jəɹ neɪm?"

"No." The gray-haired man turned toward Perrin and Egwene with a weary, slightly chiding smile, a kindly grandfather who knew his grandchildren had been up to some mischief. "My name is Geofram Bornhald," he told them. "You are Perrin, I understand. But you, young woman, what is your name?"

pɛɹɪn ɡlaʊɝɾ ət hɪm, bʌɾ ɛɡwin ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "doʊn bi sɪli, pɛɹɪn. aɪm ɛɡwin."

Perrin glowered at him, but Egwene shook her head. "Don't be silly, Perrin. I'm Egwene."

"dʒʌs pɛɹɪn, ən dʒʌst ɛɡwin," bɔɹnhəl mɝmɝd. "bʌɾ aɪ səpoʊz ɪf jə tʃɹuli ɑɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz, jə wɪʃ tə haɪd jəɹ aɪdɛntɪɾiz əz mʌtʃ əz pɑsəbəl."

"Just Perrin, and just Egwene," Bornhald murmured. "But I suppose if you truly are Darkfriends, you wish to hide your identities as much as possible."

pɛɹɪn hiv hɪmsɛlf ʌp tə hɪz niz; hi kəd ɹaɪz noʊ fɝðɝ kəz ə ðə weɪ hi wɑz baʊnd. "wi ɑɹən dɑɹkfɹɛnz," hi pɹətɛstəɾ æŋɡɹəli.

Perrin heaved himself up to his knees; he could rise no further because of the way he was bound. "We aren't Darkfriends," he protested angrily.

ðə wɝdz wɝ nɑt kəmplitli aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ bɪfɔɹ baɪɑɝ ɹitʃt hɪm. ðə mæn muv laɪk ə sneɪk. hi sɔ ðə hændəl ə hɪz oʊn æks swɪŋɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ɪm ən tʃɹaɪd tə dʌk, bʌt ðə θɪk hæf kɑɾ ɪm oʊvɝ ði ɪɹ. oʊnli ðə fæk ðəɾ i wɑz muvɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ðə bloʊ kɛpt ɪz skʌl fɹəm biɪŋ splɪt. ivən soʊ, laɪts flæʃt ɪn ɪz aɪz. bɹɛθ lɛft ɪm əz i stʃɹʌk ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hɪz hɛd ɹʌŋ, ən blʌd ɹæn daʊn ɪz tʃik.

The words were not completely out of his mouth before Byar reached him. The man moved like a snake. He saw the handle of his own axe swinging toward him and tried to duck, but the thick haft caught him over the ear. Only the fact that he was moving away from the blow kept his skull from being split. Even so, lights flashed in his eyes. Breath left him as he struck the ground. His head rung, and blood ran down his cheek.

"ju hæv noʊ ɹaɪt," ɛɡwin bɪɡæn, ən skɹimd əz ði æks hændəl wɪp təwɔɹd hɝ. ʃi θɹu hɝsɛlf əsaɪd, ən ðə bloʊ wɪsəl θɹu ɛmpti ɛɹ əz ʃi tʌmbəl tə ðə ɡɹaʊn klɔθ.

"You have no right," Egwene began, and screamed as the axe handle whipped toward her. She threw herself aside, and the blow whistled through empty air as she tumbled to the ground cloth.

"ju wɪl kip ə sɪvəl tʌŋ," baɪɑɝ sɛd, "wɛn spikɪŋ tə ən ənɔɪntəɾ ə ðə laɪt, əɹ jəl əv noʊ tʌŋ." ðə wɝst ʌv ɪt wɑz ɪz vɔɪs stɪl hæd noʊ ɪmoʊʃən əɾ ɔl. kʌɾɪŋ aʊt ðɛɹ tʌŋz wəd ɡɪv ɪm noʊ plɛʒɝ ən noʊ ɹəɡɹɛt; ɪt wɑz dʒʌst sʌmθɪŋ i wəd du.

"You will keep a civil tongue," Byar said, "when speaking to an Anointed of the Light, or you will have no tongue." The worst of it was his voice still had no emotion at all. Cutting out their tongues would give him no pleasure and no regret; it was just something he would do.

"ɡoʊ izi, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ." bɔɹnhəld lʊkt ət ðə kæptɪvz əɡɛn. "aɪ ɪkspɛk jə də nɑt noʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt ði ənɔɪntəd, əɹ əbaʊt lɔɹdz kæptən ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, də ju? noʊ, aɪ θɔt nɑt. wɛl, fəɹ tʃaɪl baɪɑɝz seɪk, ət list, tʃɹaɪ nɑt tə ɑɹɡju əɹ ʃaʊt, jɛs? aɪ wɑnt noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðət jə ʃəd wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt, ən lɛɾɪŋ æŋɡɝ ɡɛt ðə bɛɾɝ ə jə woʊn hɛlp ɛni ʌv ʌs."

"Go easy, Child Byar." Bornhald looked at the captives again. "I expect you do not know much about the Anointed, or about Lords Captain of the Children of the Light, do you? No, I thought not. Well, for Child Byar's sake, at least, try not to argue or shout, yes? I want no more than that you should walk in the Light, and letting anger get the better of you won't help any of us."

pɛɹɪn lʊkt ʌp ət ðə ɡɔnt-feɪs mæn stændɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛm. fəɹ tʃaɪl baɪɑɝz seɪk? hi noʊɾəst ðət ðə lɔɹd kæptən dɪd nɑt tɛl baɪɑɝ tə liv əm əloʊn. baɪɑɝ mɛɾ ɪz aɪz ən smaɪld; ðə smaɪl tʌtʃt oʊnli hɪz maʊθ, bʌt ðə skɪn ə hɪz feɪs dʒɹu taɪɾɝ, əntɪl ɪt lʊk laɪk ə skʌl. pɛɹɪn ʃɪvɝd.

Perrin looked up at the gaunt-faced man standing over them. For Child Byar's sake? He noticed that the Lord Captain did not tell Byar to leave them alone. Byar met his eyes and smiled; the smile touched only his mouth, but the skin of his face drew tighter, until it looked like a skull. Perrin shivered.

"aɪ hæv hɝɾ ə ðɪs θɪŋ ə mɛn ɹʌnɪŋ wɪð wʊlvz," bɔɹnhəl sɛd mjuzɪŋli, "ðoʊ aɪ hæv nɑt sin ɪt bɪfɔɹ. mɛn səpoʊzədli tɔkɪŋ wɪð wʊlvz, ən wɪð ʌðɝ kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ə fɪlθi bɪznəs. ɪt meɪks mi fɪɹ ðə læs bæɾəl ɪz ɪndid kʌmɪŋ sun."

"I have heard of this thing of men running with wolves," Bornhald said musingly, "though I have not seen it before. Men supposedly talking with wolves, and with other creatures of the Dark One. A filthy business. It makes me fear the Last Battle is indeed coming soon."

"wʊlvz ɑɹənt - " pɛɹɪn kʌɾ ɔf əz baɪɑɝz but dʒɹu bæk. teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hi wɛn ɑn ɪn ə maɪldɝ toʊn. baɪɑɝ loʊɝɾ ɪz fʊt wɪð ə dɪsəpɔɪntɪd ɡɹɪmɑs. "wʊlvz ɑɹən kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ðeɪ heɪt ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ət list, ðeɪ heɪt tʃɹɑləks, ən feɪdz." hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si ðə ɡɔnt-feɪs mæn nɑɾ əz ɪf tə hɪmsɛlf.

"Wolves aren't - " Perrin cut off as Byar's boot drew back. Taking a deep breath, he went on in a milder tone. Byar lowered his foot with a disappointed grimace. "Wolves aren't creatures of the Dark One. They hate the Dark One. At least, they hate Trollocs, and Fades." He was surprised to see the gaunt-faced man nod as if to himself.

bɔɹnhəld ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "hu toʊl jə ðæt?"

Bornhald raised an eyebrow. "Who told you that?"

"eɪ wɔɹɾɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd. ʃi skɹʌntʃt əweɪ fɹəm baɪɑɝz hiɾəd aɪz. "hi sɛd wʊlvz heɪt tʃɹɑləks, ən tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ əfɹeɪɾ ʌv wʊlvz." pɛɹɪn wɑz ɡlæd ʃi hæd nɑt mɛnʃən ɛlaɪəs.

"A Warder," Egwene said. She scrunched away from Byar's heated eyes. "He said wolves hate Trollocs, and Trollocs are afraid of wolves." Perrin was glad she had not mentioned Elyas.

"eɪ wɔɹɾɝ," ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn saɪd. "ə kɹitʃɝ ə ðə tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪtʃəz. wʌɾ ɛls wəd ðət sɔɹt tɛl ju, wən hiz ə dɑɹkfɹɛn hɪmsɛlf, ən ə sɝvən ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz? dʒju nɑt noʊ tʃɹɑləks əv wʊlvz' mʌzəlz ən tiθ, ən wʊlvz' fɝ?"

"A Warder," the gray-haired man sighed. "A creature of the Tar Valon witches. What else would that sort tell you, when he is a Darkfriend himself, and a servant of Darkfriends? Do you not know Trollocs have wolves' muzzles and teeth, and wolves' fur?"

pɛɹɪn blɪŋkt, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə klɪɹ ɪz hɛd. hɪz bɹeɪn stɪl fɛlt laɪk dʒɛlid peɪn, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ hɪɹ. hi kəd nɑt ɡɛɾ ɪz θɔts stʃɹeɪɾ ɪnʌf tə pʌzəl ɪɾ aʊt.

Perrin blinked, trying to clear his head. His brain still felt like jellied pain, but there was something wrong here. He could not get his thoughts straight enough to puzzle it out.

"nɑɾ ɔl ə ðɛm," ɛɡwin mʌɾɝd. pɛɹɪn ɡeɪv baɪɑɝ ə wɛɹi lʊk, bʌt ðə ɡɔn mæn oʊnli wɑtʃt hɝ. "sʌm ə ðɛm əv hɔɹnz, laɪk ɹæmz əɹ ɡoʊts, əɹ hɔks' biks, əɹ . . . əɹ . . . ɔl sɔɹts ə θɪŋz."

"Not all of them," Egwene muttered. Perrin gave Byar a wary look, but the gaunt man only watched her. "Some of them have horns, like rams or goats, or hawks' beaks, or . . . or . . . all sorts of things."

bɔɹnhəld ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sædli. "aɪ ɡɪv jə ɛvɹi tʃæns, ən jə dɪɡ jɝsɛlf dipɝ wɪð ɛvɹi wɝd." hi hɛld ʌp wʌn fɪŋɡɝ. "ju ɹʌn wɪð wʊlvz, kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn." ə sɛkən fɪŋɡɝ. "ju ədmɪt tə biɪŋ əkweɪntəd wɪð ə wɔɹɾɝ, ənʌðɝ kɹitʃɝ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. aɪ daʊɾ i wʊɾə toʊl jə wʌɾ i dɪɾ ɪf ɪt wɑz oʊnli ɪn pæsɪŋ." ə θɝd fɪŋɡɝ. "ju, bɔɪ, kæɹi ə tɑɹ vəlɑn mɑɹk ɪn jəɹ pɑkət. moʊs mɛn aʊtsaɪd tɑɹ vəlɑn ɡɛt ɹɪɾ ə ðoʊz əz fæst əz ðeɪ kæn. ənlɛs ðeɪ sɝv ðə tɑɹ vəlɑn wɪtʃəz." ə fɔɹθ. "ju kæɹi ə faɪɾɪŋ mænz wɛpən waɪl jə dʒɹɛs laɪk ə fɑɹmbɔɪ. ə skʌlkɝ, ðɛn." ðə θʌm ɹoʊz. "ju noʊ tʃɹɑləks, ən mɹdʒɹɑl. ðɪs fɑɹ saʊθ, oʊnli ə fju skɑlɝz ən ðoʊz u hæv tʃɹævəld ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz bɪliv ðeɪ ɑɹ ɛniθɪŋ bʌt stɔɹiz. pɝhæps juv bɪn tə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz? ɪf soʊ, tɛl mi wɛɹ? aɪ hæv tʃɹævəld ə ɡʊd dil ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz; aɪ noʊ ðɛm wɛl. noʊ? ɑ, wɛl, ðɛn." hi lʊkt əɾ ɪz spɹɛd hænd, ðən dʒɹɑpt ɪt hɑɹɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl. ðə ɡɹændfɑðɝli ɪkspɹɛʃən sɛd ðə ɡɹæntʃɪlʒɹən hæd bɪn ʌp tə səm vɛɹi sɪɹiəs mɪstʃəf ɪndid. "waɪ dʒju nɑt tɛl mi ðə tʃɹuθ ə haʊ jə keɪm tə bi ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn ðə naɪt wɪð wʊlvz?"

Bornhald shook his head sadly. "I give you every chance, and you dig yourself deeper with every word." He held up one finger. "You run with wolves, creatures of the Dark One." A second finger. "You admit to being acquainted with a Warder, another creature of the Dark One. I doubt he would have told you what he did if it was only in passing." A third finger. "You, boy, carry a Tar Valon mark in your pocket. Most men outside Tar Valon get rid of those as fast as they can. Unless they serve the Tar Valon witches." A fourth. "You carry a fighting man's weapon while you dress like a farmboy. A skulker, then." The thumb rose. "You know Trollocs, and Myrddraal. This far south, only a few scholars and those who have traveled in the Borderlands believe they are anything but stories. Perhaps you have been to the Borderlands? If so, tell me where? I have traveled a good deal in the Borderlands; I know them well. No? Ah, well, then." He looked at his spread hand, then dropped it hard on the table. The grandfatherly expression said the grandchildren had been up to some very serious mischief indeed. "Why do you not tell me the truth of how you came to be running in the night with wolves?"

ɛɡwin oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, bʌt pɛɹɪn sɔ ðə stʌbɝn sɛɾ ə hɝ dʒɔ ən nu ɹaɪɾ əweɪ ʃi wɑz gɑnə tɛl wʌn ə ðə stɔɹiz ðeɪ hæd wɝkt aʊt. ðət wəd nɑt du. nɑt naʊ, nɑt hɪɹ. hɪz hɛɾ ætʃt, ən i wɪʃt i hæd taɪm tə θɪŋk ɪɾ aʊt, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm. hu kəd tɛl wɛɹ ðɪs bɔɹnhəl hæd tʃɹævəld, wɪð wʌt lænz ən sɪɾiz i wɑz fəmɪljɝ? ɪf i kɑɾ əm ɪn ə laɪ, ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ ɡoʊɪŋ bæk tə ðə tʃɹuθ. bɔɹnhəld wəd bi kənvɪns ðeɪ wɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðɛn.

Egwene opened her mouth, but Perrin saw the stubborn set of her jaw and knew right away she was going to tell one of the stories they had worked out. That would not do. Not now, not here. His head ached, and he wished he had time to think it out, but there was no time. Who could tell where this Bornhald had traveled, with what lands and cities he was familiar? If he caught them in a lie, there would be no going back to the truth. Bornhald would be convinced they were Darkfriends, then.

"wɝ fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz," hi sɛd kwɪkli.

"We're from the Two Rivers," he said quickly.

ɛɡwin stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪm oʊpənli bɪfɔɹ ʃi kɑt hɝsɛlf, bʌɾ i pɹɛst ɑn wɪð ðə tʃɹuθ - əɹ ə vɝʒən ʌv ɪt. ðə tu ʌv əm hæd lɛf ðə tu ɹɪvɝz tə si keɪɛmlɪn. ɑn ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd hɝɾ ə ðə ɹuənz ʌv ə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾi, bʌt wən ðeɪ faʊnd ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, ðəɹ wɝ tʃɹɑləks ðɛɹ. ðə tu ʌv əm mænədʒ tə ɪskeɪp əkɹɔs ðə ɹɪvɝ ɑɹɪnɛl, bʌt baɪ ðət taɪm ðeɪ wɝ kəmplitli lɔst. ðən ðeɪ fɛl ɪn wɪð ə mæn u ɔfɝd tə ɡaɪɾ əm tə keɪɛmlɪn. hi hæd sɛɾ ɪz neɪm wɑz nʌn ə ðɛɹ bɪznəs, ən i hɑɹdli sim fɹɛnli, bʌt ðeɪ niɾəd ə ɡaɪd. ðə fɝst iðɝ ə ðɛm hæd sin ʌv wʊlvz hæd bɪn æftɝ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪɾ əpɪɹd. ɔl ðeɪ hæd bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə də wɑz haɪd soʊ ðeɪ wəd nɑt ɡɛɾ iɾən baɪ wʊlvz əɹ kɪl baɪ ðə mɛn ɑn hɔɹsəz.

Egwene stared at him openly before she caught herself, but he pressed on with the truth - or a version of it. The two of them had left the Two Rivers to see Caemlyn. On the way they had heard of the ruins of a great city, but when they found Shadar Logoth, there were Trollocs there. The two of them managed to escape across the River Arinelle, but by that time they were completely lost. Then they fell in with a man who offered to guide them to Caemlyn. He had said his name was none of their business, and he hardly seemed friendly, but they needed a guide. The first either of them had seen of wolves had been after the Children of the Light appeared. All they had been trying to do was hide so they would not get eaten by wolves or killed by the men on horses.

". . . ɪf wid noʊn jə wɝ tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt," hi fɪnɪʃt, "wiɾ əv ɡɔn tə jə fəɹ hɛlp."

". . . If we'd known you were Children of the Light," he finished, "we'd have gone to you for help."

baɪɑɝ snɔɹɾɪd wɪð dɪsbɪlif. pɛɹɪn dɪd nɑt kɛɹ oʊvɝmək; ɪf ðə lɔɹd kæptən wɑz kənvɪnst, baɪɑɝ kəd nɑt hɑɹm ðɛm. ɪt wɑz pleɪn ðət baɪɑɝ wəd stɑp bɹiðɪŋ ɪf lɔɹd kæptən bɔɹnhəl toʊld ɪm tə.

Byar snorted with disbelief. Perrin did not care overmuch; if the Lord Captain was convinced, Byar could not harm them. It was plain that Byar would stop breathing if Lord Captain Bornhald told him to.

"ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ wɔɹɾɝ ɪn ðæt," ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn sɛɾ æftɝ ə moʊmənt.

"There is no Warder in that," the gray-haired man said after a moment.

pɛɹɪnz ɪnvɛnʃən feɪl hɪm; hi nu hi ʃʊɾə teɪkən taɪm tə θɪŋk ɪɾ aʊt. ɛɡwin lɛpt ɪndə ðə bɹitʃ. "wi mɛɾ ɪm ɪn bɛɹlən. ðə sɪɾi wɑz kɹaʊɾəd wɪð mɛn u hæd kʌm daʊn fɹəm ðə maɪnz æftɝ ðə wɪntɝ, ən wi wɝ pʊɾ ət ðə seɪm teɪbəl ɪn ən ɪn. wi oʊnli tɔk tə hɪm fəɹ ðə lɛŋθ ʌv ə mil."

Perrin's invention failed him; he knew he should have taken time to think it out. Egwene leaped into the breach. "We met him in Baerlon. The city was crowded with men who had come down from the mines after the winter, and we were put at the same table in an inn. We only talked to him for the length of a meal."

pɛɹɪn bɹiðd əɡɛn. θæŋk ju, ɛɡwin.

Perrin breathed again. Thank you, Egwene.

"ɡɪv əm bæk ðɛɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ. nɑt ðə wɛpənz, ʌv kɔɹs." wən baɪɑɝ lʊkt əɾ ɪm ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, bɔɹnhəld æɾəd, "ɔɹ ɑɹ jə wʌn ə ðoʊz u hæv teɪkən tə luɾɪŋ ði ʌnɛnlaɪɾənd, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ? ɪts ə bæd bɪznəs, ðæt, jɛs? noʊ mæn kən bi ə θif ən wɔk ɪn ðə laɪt." baɪɑɝ sim tə stʃɹʌɡəl wɪð dɪsbɪlif ət ðə sədʒɛstʃən.

"Give them back their belongings, Child Byar. Not the weapons, of course." When Byar looked at him in surprise, Bornhald added, "Or are you one of those who have taken to looting the unenlightened, Child Byar? It is a bad business, that, yes? No man can be a thief and walk in the Light." Byar seemed to struggle with disbelief at the suggestion.

"ðɛn jəɹ lɛɾɪŋ əs ɡoʊ?" ɛɡwin saʊndəd sɝpɹaɪzd. pɛɹɪn lɪftəɾ ɪz hɛd tə stɛɹ ət ðə lɔɹd kæptən.

"Then you're letting us go?" Egwene sounded surprised. Perrin lifted his head to stare at the Lord Captain.

"ʌv kɔɹs nɑt, tʃaɪld," bɔɹnhəl sɛd sædli. "ju meɪ bi tɛlɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ əbaʊt biɪŋ fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, sɪns jə noʊ əbaʊt bɛɹlən, ən ðə maɪnz. bʌt ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ . . . ? ðəɾ ɪz ə neɪm vɛɹi, vɛɹi fju noʊ, moʊst ə ðɛm dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ən ɛniwʌn u noʊz ɪnʌf tə noʊ ðə neɪm, noʊz ɪnʌf nɑt tə ɡoʊ ðɛɹ. aɪ sədʒɛs jə θɪŋk ʌv ə bɛɾɝ stɔɹi ɑn ðə dʒɝni tə æmədɔɹ. jəl əv taɪm, sɪns wi mʌs pɔz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. pɹɛfɝəbli ðə tʃɹuθ, tʃaɪld. ðəɹ ɪz fɹiɾəm ɪn tʃɹuθ ən ðə laɪt."

"Of course not, child," Bornhald said sadly. "You may be telling the truth about being from the Two Rivers, since you know about Baerlon, and the mines. But Shadar Logoth . . . ? That is a name very, very few know, most of them Darkfriends, and anyone who knows enough to know the name, knows enough not to go there. I suggest you think of a better story on the journey to Amador. You will have time, since we must pause in Caemlyn. Preferably the truth, child. There is freedom in truth and the Light."

baɪɑɝ fɝɡɑt səm ə hɪz dɪfəɾəns təwɔɹd ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn. hi spʌn fɹəm ðə pɹɪznɝz, ən ðəɹ wɑz ən aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ snæp tə hɪz wɝdz. "ju kænt! ɪts nɑɾ əlaʊd!" bɔɹnhəld ɹeɪzd wʌn aɪbɹaʊ kwɪtsɪkli, ən baɪɑɝ pʊl hɪmsɛlf ʌp ʃɔɹt, swɑloʊɪŋ. "fɝɡɪv mi, maɪ lɔɹd kæptən. aɪ fɝɡɑt maɪsɛlf, ən aɪ hʌmbli bɛɡ pɑɹɾən ən səbmɪt maɪsɛlf fəɹ pɛnəns, bʌɾ əz maɪ lɔɹd kæptən hɪmsɛlf əz pɔɪntəɾ aʊt, wi mʌst ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn ɪn taɪm, ən wɪð moʊst ʌv əɹ ɹimaʊns ɡɔn, wɪl bi hɑɹd pɹɛst ɪnʌf wɪθaʊt kæɹiɪŋ pɹɪznɝz əlɔŋ."

Byar forgot some of his diffidence toward the gray-haired man. He spun from the prisoners, and there was an outraged snap to his words. "You can't! It is not allowed!" Bornhald raised one eyebrow quizzically, and Byar pulled himself up short, swallowing. "Forgive me, my Lord Captain. I forgot myself, and I humbly beg pardon and submit myself for penance, but as my Lord Captain himself has pointed out, we must reach Caemlyn in time, and with most of our remounts gone, we will be hard pressed enough without carrying prisoners along."

"ænd wʌt wəd jə sədʒɛst?" bɔɹnhəld æskt kɑmli.

"And what would you suggest?" Bornhald asked calmly.

"ðə pɛnəlti fəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪz dɛθ." ðə flæt vɔɪs meɪɾ ɪɾ ɔl ðə mɔɹ dʒɑɹɪŋ. hi maɪɾ əv bɪn sədʒɛstɪŋ stɛpɪŋ ɑn ə bʌɡ. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ tʃɹus wɪð ðə ʃædoʊ. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ mɝsi fəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz."

"The penalty for Darkfriends is death." The flat voice made it all the more jarring. He might have been suggesting stepping on a bug. "There is no truce with the Shadow. There is no mercy for Darkfriends."

"zil ɪz tə bi əplɔɾəd, tʃaɪl baɪɑɝ, bʌt, əz aɪ mʌst ɔfən tɛl maɪ sʌn, deɪn, oʊvɝzɛləsnəs kən bi ə ɡɹivəs fɔlt. ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət ðə tɛnəts ɔlsoʊ seɪ, 'noʊ mæn ɪz soʊ lɔs ðəɾ i kænɑt bi bɹɔt tə ðə laɪt.' ðiz tu ɑɹ jʌŋ. ðeɪ kænɑt jɛt bi dip ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ. ðeɪ kən jɛt bi lɛd tə ðə laɪt, ɪf ðəl oʊnli əlaʊ ðə ʃædoʊ tə bi lɪftəd fɹəm ðɛɹ aɪz. wi mʌst ɡɪv əm ðət tʃæns."

"Zeal is to be applauded, Child Byar, but, as I must often tell my son, Dain, overzealousness can be a grievous fault. Remember that the Tenets also say, 'No man is so lost that he cannot be brought to the Light.' These two are young. They cannot yet be deep in the Shadow. They can yet be led to the Light, if they will only allow the Shadow to be lifted from their eyes. We must give them that chance."

fəɹ ə moʊmən pɛɹɪn ɔlmoʊs fɛlt əfɛkʃən fəɹ ðə ɡɹændfɑðɝli mæn u stʊd bɪtwin əm ən baɪɑɝ. ðən bɔɹnhəl tɝn ɪz ɡɹændfɑðɝz smaɪl ɑn ɛɡwin.

For a moment Perrin almost felt affection for the grandfatherly man who stood between them and Byar. Then Bornhald turned his grandfather's smile on Egwene.

"ɪf jə ɹəfjuz tə kʌm tə ðə laɪt baɪ ðə taɪm wi ɹitʃ æmədɔɹ, əl bi fɔɹs tə tɝn jə oʊvɝ tə ðə kwɛstʃənɝz, ən bɪsaɪɾ əm baɪɑɝz zil ɪz bʌɾ ə kændəl bɪsaɪd ðə sʌn." ðə ɡɹeɪ-hɛɹd mæn saʊndəd laɪk ə mæn u ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd wʌɾ i mʌs du, bʌɾ u hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ʌv ɛvɝ duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ bʌɾ ɪz duɾi əz i sɔ ɪt. "ɹɪpɛnt, ɹɪnaʊns ðə dɑɹk wʌn, kʌm tə ðə laɪt, kənfɛs jəɹ sɪnz ən tɛl wʌt jə noʊ ʌv ðɪs vɪlnəs wɪð wʊlvz, ən jəl bi spɛɹd ðæt. jəl wɔk fɹi, ɪn ðə laɪt." hɪz ɡeɪz sɛntɝɾ ɑn pɛɹɪn, ən i saɪd sædli. aɪs fɪl pɛɹɪnz spaɪn. "bʌt ju, dʒʌs pɛɹɪn fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. jə kɪl tu ʌv ðə tʃɪlʒɹən." hi tʌtʃt ði æks ðət baɪɑɝ stɪl hɛld. "fɔɹ ju, aɪ fɪɹ, ə ɡɪbət weɪts ɪn æmədɔɹ."

"If you refuse to come to the Light by the time we reach Amador, I will be forced to turn you over to the Questioners, and beside them Byar's zeal is but a candle beside the sun." The gray-haired man sounded like a man who regretted what he must do, but who had no intention of ever doing anything but his duty as he saw it. "Repent, renounce the Dark One, come to the Light, confess your sins and tell what you know of this vileness with wolves, and you will be spared that. You will walk free, in the Light." His gaze centered on Perrin, and he sighed sadly. Ice filled Perrin's spine. "But you, just Perrin from the Two Rivers. You killed two of the Children." He touched the axe that Byar still held. "For you, I fear, a gibbet waits in Amador."


tʃæptɝ θɝɾiwʌn


CHAPTER 31

pleɪ fəɹ jəɹ sʌpɝ


Play for Your Supper

ɹænd nɛɹoʊɾ ɪz aɪz, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə dʌst-teɪl ðət ɹoʊz əhɛd, θɹi əɹ fɔɹ bɛnz ə ðə ɹoʊɾ əweɪ. mæt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi hɛɾəd təwɔɹd ðə waɪl hɛdʒɝoʊ əlɔŋsaɪd ðə ɹoʊdweɪ. ɪts ɛvɝɡɹin livz ən dɛnsli ɪntɝmɪʃt bɹæntʃəz wəd haɪɾ əm əz wɛl əz ə stoʊn wɔl, ɪf ðeɪ kəd faɪn ə weɪ θɹu tə ði ʌðɝ saɪd. ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɹoʊd wɑz mɑɹk baɪ ðə spɑɹs bɹaʊn skɛləɾənz ə hɛd-haɪ bʊʃəz, ən bɪɑnd wɑz ən oʊpən fil fəɹ hæf ə maɪl tə ðə wʊdz. ɪt maɪɾ əv bɪn pɑɹɾ ʌv ə fɑɹm nɑt tu lɔŋ əbændənd, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɔfɝd noʊ kwɪk haɪɾɪŋ pleɪs. hi tʃɹaɪd tə dʒʌdʒ ðə spiɾ ə ðə dʌst-teɪl, ən ðə wɪnd.

Rand narrowed his eyes, watching the dust-tail that rose ahead, three or four bends of the road away. Mat was already headed toward the wild hedgerow alongside the roadway. Its evergreen leaves and densely intermeshed branches would hide them as well as a stone wall, if they could find a way through to the other side. The other side of the road was marked by the sparse brown skeletons of head-high bushes, and beyond was an open field for half a mile to the woods. It might have been part of a farm not too long abandoned, but it offered no quick hiding place. He tried to judge the speed of the dust-tail, and the wind.

ə sʌɾən ɡʌst swɝld ɹoʊd dʌst ʌp ɝaʊn hɪm, əbskjʊɹɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. hi blɪŋkt ən ədʒʌstəd ðə pleɪn, dɑɹk skɑɹf əkɹɔs ɪz noʊz ən maʊθ. nʌn tu klin naʊ, ɪt meɪɾ ɪz feɪs ɪtʃ, bʌɾ ɪt kɛpt ɪm fɹəm ɪnheɪlɪŋ dʌst wɪð ɛvɹi bɹɛθ. ə fɑɹmɝ hæd ɡɪvən ɪt tə hɪm, ə lɔŋ-feɪs mæn wɪð ɡɹuvz ɪn ɪz tʃiks fɹəm wɝi.

A sudden gust swirled road dust up around him, obscuring everything. He blinked and adjusted the plain, dark scarf across his nose and mouth. None too clean now, it made his face itch, but it kept him from inhaling dust with every breath. A farmer had given it to him, a long-faced man with grooves in his cheeks from worry.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jəɹ ɹʌnɪŋ fɹʌm," hi hæd sɛd wɪð ən æŋkʃəs fɹaʊn, "æn aɪ doʊnt wɑn tə. jə ʌndɝstænd? maɪ fæmli." əbɹʌpli ðə fɑɹmɝ hæd dʌɡ tu lɔŋ skɑɹvz aʊɾ ə hɪz koʊt pɑkəɾ ən pʊʃt ðə tæŋɡəl ʌv wʊl ət ðɛm. "ɪts nɑt mʌtʃ, bʌt hɪɹ. bɪlɔŋ tə maɪ bɔɪz. ðeɪv ʌðɝz. jə doʊnt noʊ mi, ʌndɝstænd? ɪts hɑɹd taɪmz."

"I don't know what you're running from," he had said with an anxious frown, "and I don't want to. You understand? My family." Abruptly the farmer had dug two long scarves out of his coat pocket and pushed the tangle of wool at them. "It's not much, but here. Belong to my boys. They have others. You don't know me, understand? It's hard times."

ɹænd tʃɹɛʒɝd ðə skɑɹf. ðə lɪst ə kaɪndnəsəz i hæd meɪɾ ɪn ɪz maɪn ɪn ðə deɪz sɪns waɪtbɹɪdʒ wɑz ə ʃɔɹt wʌn, ən i dɪd nɑt bɪliv ɪt wəd ɡɛt mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ.

Rand treasured the scarf. The list of kindnesses he had made in his mind in the days since Whitebridge was a short one, and he did not believe it would get much longer.

mæt, ɔl bʌɾ ɪz aɪz hɪɾən baɪ ðə skɑɹf ɹæpt ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd, hʌntəd swɪfli əlɔŋ ðə tɔl hɛdʒɝoʊ, pʊlɪŋ ət ðə lifi bɹæntʃəz. ɹænd tʌtʃt ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk hɪlt əɾ ɪz bɛlt, bʌt lɛɾ ɪz hæn fɔl əweɪ. wʌns ɔlɹɛɾi, kʌɾɪŋ ə hoʊl θɹu ə hɛdʒ hæɾ ɔlmoʊst ɡɪvən əm əweɪ. ðə dʌst-teɪl wɑz muvɪŋ təwɔɹd ðɛm, ən steɪɪŋ təɡɛðɝ tu lɔŋ. nɑt ðə wɪnd. ət list ɪt wɑz nɑt ɹeɪnɪŋ. ɹeɪn sɛɾəld ðə dʌst. noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ hɑɹɾ ɪt fɛl, ɪt nɛvɝ tɝn ðə hɑɹd-pækt ɹoʊd tə mʌd, bʌt wən ɪt ɹeɪn ðəɹ wɑz noʊ dʌst. dʌst wɑz ði oʊnli wɔɹnɪŋ ðeɪ hæd bɪfɔɹ huɛvɝ ɪt wɑz keɪm kloʊs ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ. səmtaɪmz ðət wɑz tu leɪt.

Mat, all but his eyes hidden by the scarf wrapped around his head, hunted swiftly along the tall hedgerow, pulling at the leafy branches. Rand touched the heron-marked hilt at his belt, but let his hand fall away. Once already, cutting a hole through a hedge had almost given them away. The dust-tail was moving toward them, and staying together too long. Not the wind. At least it was not raining. Rain settled the dust. No matter how hard it fell, it never turned the hard-packed road to mud, but when it rained there was no dust. Dust was the only warning they had before whoever it was came close enough to hear. Sometimes that was too late.

"hɪɹ," mæt kɔl sɔfli. hi sim tə stɛp ɹaɪt θɹu ðə hɛdʒ. ɹænd hɝid tə ðə spɑt. sʌmwʌn hæd kʌɾ ə hoʊl ðɛɹ, wʌns. ɪt wɑz pɑɹtli ɡɹoʊn oʊvɝ, ən fɹəm θɹi fiɾ əweɪ ɪt lʊkt əz sɑləɾ əz ðə ɹɛst, bʌt kloʊs ʌp ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ə θɪn skɹin ə bɹæntʃəz. əz i pʊʃt θɹu, hi hɝd hɔɹsəz kʌmɪŋ. nɑt ðə wɪnd.

"Here," Mat called softly. He seemed to step right through the hedge. Rand hurried to the spot. Someone had cut a hole there, once. It was partly grown over, and from three feet away it looked as solid as the rest, but close up there was only a thin screen of branches. As he pushed through, he heard horses coming. Not the wind.

hi kɹaʊtʃt bɪhaɪn ðə bɛɹli kʌvɝɾ oʊpənɪŋ, klʌtʃɪŋ ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹɾ əz ðə hɔɹsmən ɹoʊd baɪ. faɪv . . . sɪks . . . sɛvən ə ðɛm. pleɪnli dʒɹɛs mɛn, bʌt sɔɹdz ən spɪɹz sɛd ðeɪ wɝ nɑt vɪlɪdʒɝz. səm wɔɹ lɛðɝ tunɪks wɪð mɛɾəl stʌdz, ən tu hæd ɹaʊn stil kæps. mɝtʃəns' ɡɑɹdz, pɝhæps, bɪtwin haɪɹɪŋz. pɝhæps.

He crouched behind the barely covered opening, clutching the hilt of his sword as the horsemen rode by. Five . . . six . . . seven of them. Plainly dressed men, but swords and spears said they were not villagers. Some wore leather tunics with metal studs, and two had round steel caps. Merchants' guards, perhaps, between hirings. Perhaps.

wʌn ə ðɛm kæʒəwəli swʌŋ ɪz aɪz təwɔɹd ðə hɛdʒ əz i wɛn baɪ ði oʊpənɪŋ, ən ɹænd bɛɹɾ ən ɪntʃ ə hɪz sɔɹd. mæt snɑɹəl saɪlənli laɪk ə kɔɹnɝd bædʒɝ, skwɪntɪŋ əbʌv ɪz skɑɹf. hɪz hænd wɑz ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt; hi ɔlweɪz klʌtʃt ðə dæɡɝ fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ wən ðəɹ wɑz deɪnʒɝ. ɹænd wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ʃʊɹ ɪf ɪt wɑz tə pɹətɛk hɪmsɛlf əɹ tə pɹətɛk ðə ɹubi-hɪltɪd dæɡɝ. ʌv leɪt mæt sim tə fɝɡɛɾ i hæɾ ə baʊ, səmtaɪmz.

One of them casually swung his eyes toward the hedge as he went by the opening, and Rand bared an inch of his sword. Mat snarled silently like a cornered badger, squinting above his scarf. His hand was under his coat; he always clutched the dagger from Shadar Logoth when there was danger. Rand was no longer sure if it was to protect himself or to protect the ruby-hilted dagger. Of late Mat seemed to forget he had a bow, sometimes.

ðə ɹaɪɾɝz pæst əɾ ə sloʊ tʃɹɑt, ɡoʊɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ wɪð ə pɝpəs bʌt nɑt tu ɡɹeɪɾ ə heɪst. dʌst sɪftɪd θɹu ðə hɛdʒ.

The riders passed at a slow trot, going somewhere with a purpose but not too great a haste. Dust sifted through the hedge.

ɹænd weɪɾəd əntɪl ðə klɑp ə ðə hʊvz feɪɾəd bɪfɔɹ i stʌk ɪz hɛd kɔʃəsli bæk θɹu ðə hoʊl. ðə dʌst-teɪl wɑz wɛl daʊn ðə ɹoʊd, ɡoʊɪŋ ðə weɪ ðeɪ hæd kʌm. istwɝd ðə skaɪ wɑz klɪɹ. hi klaɪmd aʊɾ ɑntu ðə ɹoʊdweɪ, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə kɑləm ə dʌs muv wɛst.

Rand waited until the clop of the hooves faded before he stuck his head cautiously back through the hole. The dust-tail was well down the road, going the way they had come. Eastward the sky was clear. He climbed out onto the roadway, watching the column of dust move west.

"nɑɾ æftɝ ʌs," hi sɛd, hæfweɪ bɪtwin ə steɪtmən ən ə kwɛstʃən.

"Not after us," he said, halfway between a statement and a question.

mæt skɹæmbəld aʊɾ æftɝ hɪm, lʊkɪŋ wɛɹəli ɪn boʊθ dɝɛkʃənz. "meɪbi," hi sɛd. "meɪbi."

Mat scrambled out after him, looking warily in both directions. "Maybe," he said. "Maybe."

ɹænd hæd noʊ aɪdiə wɪtʃ weɪ hi mɛn ɪt, bʌɾ i nɑɾəd. meɪbi. ɪt hæd nɑt bɪɡʌn laɪk ðɪs, ðɛɹ dʒɝni daʊn ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd.

Rand had no idea which way he meant it, but he nodded. Maybe. It had not begun like this, their journey down the Caemlyn Road.

fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm æftɝ livɪŋ waɪtbɹɪdʒ, ɹænd wəd sʌɾənli faɪn hɪmsɛlf stɛɹɪŋ bæk daʊn ðə ɹoʊd bɪhaɪn ðɛm. səmtaɪmz i wəd si sʌmwʌn u meɪɾ ɪz bɹɛθ kætʃ, ə tɔl, skɪni mæn hɝiɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹoʊd, əɹ ə læŋki, waɪt-hɛɹd fɛloʊ ʌp bɪsaɪd ðə dʒɹaɪvɝ ɑn ə wæɡən, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz ə pæk-pɛdlɝ, əɹ fɑɹmɝz meɪkɪŋ ðɛɹ weɪ tə mɑɹkət, nɛvɝ tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn. hoʊp feɪɾəd əz ðə deɪz pæst.

For a long time after leaving Whitebridge, Rand would suddenly find himself staring back down the road behind them. Sometimes he would see someone who made his breath catch, a tall, skinny man hurrying up the road, or a lanky, white-haired fellow up beside the driver on a wagon, but it was always a pack-peddler, or farmers making their way to market, never Thom Merrilin. Hope faded as the days passed.

ðəɹ wɑz kənsɪɾɝəbəl tʃɹæfɪk ɑn ðə ɹoʊd, wæɡənz ən kɑɹts, pipəl ɑn hɔɹsəz ən pipəl əfʊt. ðeɪ keɪm sɪŋɡli ən ɪn ɡɹups, ə tʃɹeɪn ə mɝtʃəns' wæɡənz əɹ ə dʌzən hɔɹsmən təɡɛðɝ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt dʒæm ðə ɹoʊd, ən ɔfən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ ɪn saɪɾ ɪksɛp ði ɔl bʌt lifləs tʃɹiz laɪnɪŋ ðə hɑɹd-pækt ɹoʊdbd, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ sɝɾənli mɔɹ pipəl tʃɹævlɪŋ ðən ɹænd hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz.

There was considerable traffic on the road, wagons and carts, people on horses and people afoot. They came singly and in groups, a train of merchants' wagons or a dozen horsemen together. They did not jam the road, and often there was nothing in sight except the all but leafless trees lining the hard-packed roadbed, but there were certainly more people traveling than Rand had ever seen in the Two Rivers.

moʊs tʃɹævəld ɪn ðə seɪm dɝɛkʃən ðət ðeɪ dɪd, istwɝd təwɔɹd keɪɛmlɪn. səmtaɪmz ðeɪ ɡɑɾ ə ɹaɪɾ ɪn ə fɑɹmɝz wæɡən fəɹ ə lɪɾəl dɪstəns, ə maɪl, əɹ faɪv, bʌt mɔɹ ɔfən ðeɪ wɔkt. mɛn ɑn hɔɹsbæk ðeɪ əvɔɪɾəd; wən ðeɪ spɑɾəd ivən wʌn ɹaɪɾɝ ɪn ðə dɪstəns ðeɪ skɹæmbəld ɔf ðə ɹoʊɾ ən hɪɾ əntɪl i wɑz pæst. nʌn ɛvɝ wɔɹ ə blæk kloʊk, ən ɹænd dɪd nɑt ɹɪli θɪŋk ə feɪd wəd lɛɾ əm si hɪm kʌmɪŋ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn teɪkɪŋ tʃænsəz. ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðə hæfmən ðeɪ fɪɹd.

Most traveled in the same direction that they did, eastward toward Caemlyn. Sometimes they got a ride in a farmer's wagon for a little distance, a mile, or five, but more often they walked. Men on horseback they avoided; when they spotted even one rider in the distance they scrambled off the road and hid until he was past. None ever wore a black cloak, and Rand did not really think a Fade would let them see him coming, but there was no point in taking chances. In the beginning it was just the Halfmen they feared.

ðə fɝs vɪlədʒ æftɝ waɪtbɹɪdʒ lʊk soʊ mʌtʃ laɪk ɛmənz fil ðət ɹændz stɛps dʒɹæɡd wən i sɔ ɪt. θætʃt ɹufs wɪð haɪ piks, ən ɡʊdwaɪvz ɪn ðɛɹ eɪpɹənz ɡɑsəpɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə fɛnsəz bɪtwin ðɛɹ haʊsəz, ən tʃɪlʒɹən pleɪɪŋ ɑn ə vɪlədʒ ɡɹin. ðə wɪmənz hɛɹ hʌŋ ənbɹeɪɾɪd ɝaʊn ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ən ʌðɝ smɔl θɪŋz wɝ dɪfɹənt, tu, bʌt ðə hoʊl təɡɛðɝ wɑz laɪk hoʊm. kaʊz kɹɑpt ɑn ðə ɡɹin, ən ɡis wɑɾəld sɛlf-ɪmpɔɹɾəntli əkɹɔs ðə ɹoʊd. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən tʌmbəld, læfɪŋ, ɪn ðə dʌst wɛɹ ðə ɡɹæs wɑz ɡɔn ɔltəɡɛðɝ. ðeɪ dɪd nɑɾ ivən lʊk ɝaʊnd wən ɹænd ən mæt wɛn baɪ. ðət wɑz ənʌðɝ θɪŋ ðət wɑz dɪfɹənt. stʃɹeɪnʒɝz wɝ noʊ ɑɾəti ðɛɹ; tu mɔɹ dɪd nɑt dʒɹɔ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə sɛkənd ɡlæns. vɪlədʒ dɑɡz oʊnli ɹeɪz ðɛɹ hɛdz tə snɪf əz i ən mæt pæst; nʌn stɝd ðɛmsɛlvz.

The first village after Whitebridge looked so much like Emond's Field that Rand's steps dragged when he saw it. Thatched roofs with high peaks, and goodwives in their aprons gossiping over the fences between their houses, and children playing on a village green. The women's hair hung unbraided around their shoulders, and other small things were different, too, but the whole together was like home. Cows cropped on the green, and geese waddled self-importantly across the road. The children tumbled, laughing, in the dust where the grass was gone altogether. They did not even look around when Rand and Mat went by. That was another thing that was different. Strangers were no oddity there; two more did not draw so much as a second glance. Village dogs only raised their heads to sniff as he and Mat passed; none stirred themselves.

ɪt wɑz kʌmɪŋ ɑn ivnɪŋ əz ðeɪ wɛn θɹu ðə vɪlədʒ, ən i fɛlt ə pæŋ ə hoʊmsɪknəs əz laɪts əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz. noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɪt lʊks laɪk, ə smɔl vɔɪs wɪspɝɾ ɪn ɪz maɪnd, ɪɾ ɪzən ɹɪli hoʊm. ivən ɪf jə ɡoʊ ɪndə wʌn ə ðoʊz haʊsəz tæm woʊn bi ðɛɹ. ɪf i wɑz, kəd jə lʊk ɪm ɪn ðə feɪs? jə noʊ, naʊ, doʊn ju? ɪksɛp fəɹ lɪɾəl θɪŋz laɪk wɛɹ jə kʌm fɹəm ən u jə ɑɹ. noʊ fivɝ-dʒɹimz. hi hʌntʃt ɪz ʃoʊldɝz əɡɛns tɔntɪŋ læftɝ ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd. jə maɪɾ əz wɛl stɑp, ðə vɔɪs snɪkɝd. wʌn pleɪs ɪz əz ɡʊɾ əz ənʌðɝ wən jə ɑɹən fɹəm ɛniwɛɹ, ən ðə dɑɹk wʌn əz jə mɑɹkt.

It was coming on evening as they went through the village, and he felt a pang of homesickness as lights appeared in the windows. No matter what it looks like, a small voice whispered in his mind, it isn't really home. Even if you go into one of those houses Tam won't be there. If he was, could you look him in the face? You know, now, don't you? Except for little things like where you come from and who you are. No fever-dreams. He hunched his shoulders against taunting laughter inside his head. You might as well stop, the voice snickered. One place is as good as another when you aren't from anywhere, and the Dark One has you marked.

mæt tʌɡd əɾ ɪz sliv, bʌɾ i pʊld lus ən sɹɾ ət ðə haʊsəz. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə stɑp, bʌɾ i dɪd wɑnə lʊk ən ɹɪmɛmbɝ. soʊ mʌtʃ laɪk hoʊm, bʌt jəl nɛvɝ si ðəɾ əɡɛn, wɪl ju?

Mat tugged at his sleeve, but he pulled loose and sared at the houses. He did not want to stop, but he did want to look and remember. So much like home, but you'll never see that again, will you?

mæt jæŋkt əɾ ɪm əɡɛn. hɪz feɪs wɑz tɔt, ðə skɪn ɝaʊn ɪz maʊθ ən aɪz waɪt. "kʌm ɑn," mæt mʌɾɝd. "kʌm ɑn." hi lʊkt ət ðə vɪlədʒ əz ɪf i səspɛktəd sʌmθɪŋ ə haɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ. "kʌm ɑn. wi kæn stɑp jɛt."

Mat yanked at him again. His face was taut, the skin around his mouth and eyes white. "Come on," Mat muttered. "Come on." He looked at the village as if he suspected something of hiding there. "Come on. We can't stop yet."

ɹænd tɝn ɪn ə kəmplit sɝkəl, teɪkɪŋ ɪn ðə hoʊl vɪlədʒ, ən saɪd. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt vɛɹi fɑɹ fɹəm waɪtbɹɪdʒ. ɪf ðə mɹdʒɹɑl kəd ɡɛt pæst waɪtbɹɪdʒəz wɔl wɪθaʊt biɪŋ sin, ɪt wəɾ əv noʊ tʃɹʌbəl əɾ ɔl sɝtʃɪŋ ðɪs smɔl vɪlədʒ. hi lɛt hɪmsɛlf bi dʒɹɔn ɑn ɪndə ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd bɪɑnd, əntɪl ðə θætʃ-ɹuf haʊsəz wɝ lɛf bɪhaɪnd.

Rand turned in a complete circle, taking in the whole village, and sighed. They were not very far from Whitebridge. If the Myrddraal could get past Whitebridge's wall without being seen, it would have no trouble at all searching this small village. He let himself be drawn on into the countryside beyond, until the thatch-roofed houses were left behind.

naɪt fɛl bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ faʊn ə spɑt baɪ munlaɪt, ʌndɝ səm bʊʃəz stɪl bɛɹɪŋ ðɛɹ dɛd livz. ðeɪ fɪl ðɛɹ bɛliz wɪð koʊld wɔɾɝ fɹəm ə ʃæloʊ ɹɪvjulɛt nɑt fɑɹ əweɪ ən kɝld ʌp ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɹæpt ɪn ðɛɹ kloʊks, wɪθaʊɾ ə faɪɝ. ə faɪɝ kəd bi sin; bɛɾɝ tə bi koʊld.

Night fell before they found a spot by moonlight, under some bushes still bearing their dead leaves. They filled their bellies with cold water from a shallow rivulet not far away and curled up on the ground, wrapped in their cloaks, without a fire. A fire could be seen; better to be cold.

ənizi wɪð ɪz mɛmɹiz, ɹænd woʊk ɔfən, ən ɛvɹi taɪm i kəd hɪɹ mæt mʌɾɝɪŋ ən tɔsɪŋ ɪn ɪz slip. hi dɪd nɑt dʒɹim, ðəɾ i kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt slip wɛl. jəl nɛvɝ si hoʊm əɡɛn.

Uneasy with his memories, Rand woke often, and every time he could hear Mat muttering and tossing in his sleep. He did not dream, that he could remember, but he did not sleep well. You'll never see home again.

ðət wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli naɪt ðeɪ spɛnt wɪð dʒʌs ðɛɹ kloʊks tə pɹətɛkt əm fɹəm ðə wɪnd, ən səmtaɪmz ðə ɹeɪn, koʊld ən soʊkɪŋ. ɪt wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli mil ðeɪ meɪd fɹəm nʌθɪŋ bʌt koʊld wɔɾɝ. bɪtwin əm ðeɪ hæɾ ɪnʌf kɔɪnz fəɹ ə fju milz əɾ ən ɪn, bʌɾ ə bɛd fəɹ ðə naɪt wəd teɪk tu mʌtʃ. θɪŋz kɑs mɔɹ aʊtsaɪd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, mɔɹ ðɪs saɪɾ ə ði ɑɹɪnɛl ðən ɪn bɛɹlən. wʌt mʌni ðeɪ hæd lɛf hæd tə bi seɪv fəɹ ən ɪmɝdʒənsi.

That was not the only night they spent with just their cloaks to protect them from the wind, and sometimes the rain, cold and soaking. It was not the only meal they made from nothing but cold water. Between them they had enough coins for a few meals at an inn, but a bed for the night would take too much. Things cost more outside the Two Rivers, more this side of the Arinelle than in Baerlon. What money they had left had to be saved for an emergency.

wʌn æftɝnun ɹænd mɛnʃən ðə dæɡɝ wɪð ðə ɹubi ɪn ɪts hɪlt, waɪl ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹʌdʒɪŋ daʊn ðə ɹoʊd wɪð bɛliz tu ɛmpti tə ɹʌmbəl, ən ðə sʌn loʊ ən wik, ən nʌθɪŋ ɪn vju fəɹ ðə kʌmɪŋ naɪt bʌt mɔɹ bʊʃəz. dɑɹk klaʊdz bɪlt ʌp oʊvɝhɛd fəɹ ɹeɪn dʊɹɪŋ ðə naɪt. hi hoʊp ðeɪ wɝ lʌki; meɪbi noʊ mɔɹ ðən ən aɪsi dʒɹɪzəl.

One afternoon Rand mentioned the dagger with the ruby in its hilt, while they were trudging down the road with bellies too empty to rumble, and the sun low and weak, and nothing in view for the coming night but more bushes. Dark clouds built up overhead for rain during the night. He hoped they were lucky; maybe no more than an icy drizzle.

hi wɛn ɑn ə fju stɛps bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪz ðət mæt hæd stɑpt. hi stɑpt, tu, ɹɪəlɪŋ ɪz toʊz ɪn ɪz buts. ət list ɪz fit fɛlt wɔɹm. hi iz ðə stʃɹæps əkɹɔs ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. hɪz blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl ən tɑmz bʌndəl kloʊk wɝ nɑt hɛvi, bʌɾ ivən ə fju paʊnz weɪd hɛvi æftɝ maɪlz ɑn ən ɛmpti stʌmək. "wʌts ðə mæɾɝ, mæt?" hi sɛd.

He went on a few steps before he realized that Mat had stopped. He stopped, too, wriggling his toes in his boots. At least his feet felt warm. He eased the straps across his shoulders. His blanketroll and Thom's bundled cloak were not heavy, but even a few pounds weighed heavy after miles on an empty stomach. "What's the matter, Mat?" he said.

"waɪ ɑɹ jə soʊ æŋkʃəs tə sɛl ɪt?" mæt dɪmændəɾ æŋɡɹəli. "aɪ faʊn ɪt, æftɝ ɔl. jə ɛvɝ θɪŋk aɪ maɪt laɪk tə kip ɪt? fəɹ ə waɪl, ɛniweɪ. ɪf jə wɑnə sɛl sʌmθɪŋ, sɛl ðət blʌɾi sɔɹd!"

"Why are you so anxious to sell it?" Mat demanded angrily. "I found it, after all. You ever think I might like to keep it? For a while, anyway. If you want to sell something, sell that bloody sword!"

ɹænd ɹʌbd ɪz hæn əlɔŋ ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk hɪlt. "maɪ fɑðɝ ɡeɪv ðɪs sɔɹd tə mi. ɪt wɑz hɪz. aɪ wʊdn æsk jə tə sɛl sʌmθɪŋ jəɹ fɑðɝ ɡeɪv ju. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, mæt, dʒju laɪk ɡoʊɪŋ hʌŋɡɹi? ɛniweɪ, ivən ɪf aɪ kəd faɪn sʌmbɑɾi tə baɪ ɪt, haʊ mʌtʃ wəɾ ə sɔɹd bɹɪŋ? wʌt wəɾ ə fɑɹmɝ wɑnt wɪð ə sɔɹd? ðət ɹubi wəd fɛtʃ ɪnʌf tə teɪk əs ɔl ðə weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn ɪn ə kæɹɪdʒ. meɪbi ɔl ðə weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ən wiɾ iɾ ɛvɹi mil ɪn ən ɪn, ən slip ɛvɹi naɪɾ ɪn ə bɛd. meɪbi jə laɪk ði aɪdiə ʌv wɔkɪŋ hæfweɪ əkɹɔs ðə wɝld ən slipɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd?" hi ɡlɛɹɾ ət mæt, ən ɪz fɹɛnd ɡlɛɹd bæk.

Rand rubbed his hand along the heron-marked hilt. "My father gave this sword to me. It was his. I wouldn't ask you to sell something your father gave you. Blood and ashes, Mat, do you like going hungry? Anyway, even if I could find somebody to buy it, how much would a sword bring? What would a farmer want with a sword? That ruby would fetch enough to take us all the way to Caemlyn in a carriage. Maybe all the way to Tar Valon. And we'd eat every meal in an inn, and sleep every night in a bed. Maybe you like the idea of walking halfway across the world and sleeping on the ground?" He glared at Mat, and his friend glared back.

ðeɪ stʊd laɪk ðəɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹoʊɾ əntɪl mæt sʌɾənli ɡeɪv ən ənkʌmftəɹbəl ʃɹʌɡ, ən dʒɹɑpt ɪz aɪz tə ðə ɹoʊd. "hu wəɾ aɪ sɛl ɪt tə, ɹænd? ə fɑɹmɝ wəɾ əv tə peɪ ɪn tʃɪkənz; wi kʊdn baɪ ə kæɹɪdʒ wɪð tʃɪkənz. ən ɪf aɪ ivən ʃoʊɾ ɪɾ ɪn ɛni vɪlədʒ wiv bɪn θɹu, ðeɪd pɹɑbli θɪŋk wi stoʊl ɪt. ðə laɪt noʊz wʌt wəd hæpən ðɛn."

They stood like that in the middle of the road until Mat suddenly gave an uncomfortable shrug, and dropped his eyes to the road. "Who would I sell it to, Rand? A farmer would have to pay in chickens; we couldn't buy a carriage with chickens. And if I even showed it in any village we've been through, they'd probably think we stole it. The Light knows what would happen then."

æftɝ ə mɪnət ɹænd nɑɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli. "jɔɹ ɹaɪt. aɪ noʊ ɪt. aɪm sɑɹi; aɪ dɪdn min tə snæp ət ju. ɪts oʊnli ðəɾ aɪm hʌŋɡɹi ən maɪ fit hɝt."

After a minute Rand nodded reluctantly. "You're right. I know it. I'm sorry; I didn't mean to snap at you. It's only that I'm hungry and my feet hurt."

"maɪn, tu." ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd daʊn ðə ɹoʊɾ əɡɛn, wɔkɪŋ ivən mɔɹ wɛɹəli ðən bɪfɔɹ. ðə wɪnd ɡʌstɪɾ ʌp, bloʊɪŋ dʌst ɪn ðɛɹ feɪsəz. "maɪn, tu." mæt kɔft.

"Mine, too." They started down the road again, walking even more wearily than before. The wind gusted up, blowing dust in their faces. "Mine, too." Mat coughed.

fɑɹmz dɪd pɹəvaɪd səm milz ən ə fju naɪts aʊɾ ə ðə koʊld. ə heɪstæk wɑz nɪɹli əz wɔɹm əz ə ɹum wɪð ə faɪɝ, ət lis kəmpɛɹd tə laɪɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə bʊʃəz, ən ə heɪstæk, ivən wʌn wɪθaʊɾ ə tɑɹp oʊvɝ ɪt, kɛpt ɔl bʌt ðə hɛviəst ɹeɪn ɔf, ɪf jə dʌɡ jɝsɛlf ɪn dipli ɪnʌf. səmtaɪmz mæt tʃɹaɪɾ ɪz hæn ət stilɪŋ ɛɡz, ən wʌns i ətɛmptəd tə mɪlk ə kaʊ lɛft ənətɛndɪd, steɪkt aʊɾ ɑn ə lɔŋ ɹoʊp tə kɹɑp ɪn ə fild. moʊs fɑɹmz hæd dɑɡz, ðoʊ, ən fɑɹm dɑɡz wɝ wɑtʃfəl. ə tu-maɪl ɹʌn wɪð beɪɪŋ haʊnz ət ðɛɹ hilz wɑz tu haɪ ə pɹaɪs fəɹ tu əɹ θɹi ɛɡz əz ɹænd sɔ ɪt, ɪspɛʃli wən ðə dɑɡz səmtaɪmz tʊk aʊɝz tə ɡoʊ əweɪ ən lɛɾ əm daʊn aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹi wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd teɪkən ʃɛltɝ. ði aʊɝz wɝ wʌɾ i ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd.

Farms did provide some meals and a few nights out of the cold. A haystack was nearly as warm as a room with a fire, at least compared to lying under the bushes, and a haystack, even one without a tarp over it, kept all but the heaviest rain off, if you dug yourself in deeply enough. Sometimes Mat tried his hand at stealing eggs, and once he attempted to milk a cow left unattended, staked out on a long rope to crop in a field. Most farms had dogs, though, and farm dogs were watchful. A two-mile run with baying hounds at their heels was too high a price for two or three eggs as Rand saw it, especially when the dogs sometimes took hours to go away and let them down out of the tree where they had taken shelter. The hours were what he regretted.

hi dɪd nɑt ɹɪli laɪk duɪŋ ɪt, bʌt ɹænd pɹəfɝd tə əpɹoʊtʃ ə fɑɹmhaʊs oʊpənli ɪn bɹɔd deɪlaɪt. naʊ ən əɡɛn ðeɪ hæd ðə dɑɡz sɛɾ ɑn əm ɛniweɪ, wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd biɪŋ sɛd, fəɹ ðə ɹumɝz ən ðə taɪmz meɪɾ ɛvɹiwʌn u lɪvd əpɑɹt fɹəm ʌðɝ pipəl nɝvəs əbaʊt stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, bʌɾ ɔfən ən aʊɝ əɹ soʊ tʃɑpɪŋ wʊɾ əɹ hɔlɪŋ wɔɾɝ wəɾ ɝn ə mil ən ə bɛd, ivən ɪf ðə bɛd wɑz ə paɪl ə stʃɹɔ ɪn ðə bɑɹn. bʌɾ ən aʊɝ əɹ tu duɪŋ tʃɔɹz wɑz ən aʊɝ əɹ tu ʌv deɪlaɪt wən ðeɪ wɝ stændɪŋ stɪl, ən aʊɝ əɹ tu fəɹ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl tə kætʃ ʌp. səmtaɪmz i wʌndɝd haʊ mɛni maɪlz ə feɪd kəd kʌvɝ ɪn ən aʊɝ. hi bɪɡɹʌdʒd ɛvɹi mɪnəɾ ʌv ɪt - ðoʊ ædmɪɾɪdli nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ wən i wɑz wʊlfɪŋ daʊn ə ɡʊdwaɪfs hɑt sup. ən wən ðeɪ hæd noʊ fud, noʊɪŋ ðeɪ hæd spɛn ɛvɹi pɑsəbəl mɪnət muvɪŋ təwɔɹd keɪɛmlɪn dɪd nɑt də mʌtʃ tə suð ən ɛmpti bɛli. ɹænd kəd nɑt meɪk ʌp ɪz maɪn ɪf ɪt wɑz wɝs tə luz taɪm əɹ ɡoʊ hʌŋɡɹi, bʌt mæt wɛn bɪɑnd wɝiɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪz bɛli əɹ pɝsut.

He did not really like doing it, but Rand preferred to approach a farmhouse openly in broad daylight. Now and again they had the dogs set on them anyway, without a word being said, for the rumors and the times made everyone who lived apart from other people nervous about strangers, but often an hour or so chopping wood or hauling water would earn a meal and a bed, even if the bed was a pile of straw in the barn. But an hour or two doing chores was an hour or two of daylight when they were standing still, an hour or two for the Myrddraal to catch up. Sometimes he wondered how many miles a Fade could cover in an hour. He begrudged every minute of it - though admittedly not so much when he was wolfing down a goodwife's hot soup. And when they had no food, knowing they had spent every possible minute moving toward Caemlyn did not do much to soothe an empty belly. Rand could not make up his mind if it was worse to lose time or go hungry, but Mat went beyond worrying about his belly or pursuit.

"wʌt də wi noʊ əbaʊt ðɛm, ɛniweɪ?" mæt dɪmændəd wʌn æftɝnun waɪl ðeɪ wɝ mʌkɪŋ aʊt stɔlz ɑn ə smɔl fɑɹm.

"What do we know about them, anyway?" Mat demanded one afternoon while they were mucking out stalls on a small farm.

"laɪt, mæt, wʌt də ðeɪ noʊ əbaʊɾ ʌs?" ɹænd snizd. ðeɪ wɝ wɝkɪŋ stʃɹɪp tə ðə weɪst, ən swɛɾ ən stʃɹɔ kʌvɝɾ əm boʊθ lɪbɝəli, ən moʊts ə stʃɹɔ-dʌs hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ. "wʌɾ aɪ noʊ ɪz ðəl ɡɪv əs səm ɹoʊs læm ən ə ɹil bɛd tə slip ɪn."

"Light, Mat, what do they know about us?" Rand sneezed. They were working stripped to the waist, and sweat and straw covered them both liberally, and motes of straw-dust hung in the air. "What I know is they'll give us some roast lamb and a real bed to sleep in."

mæt dʌɡ hɪz heɪfɔɹk ɪndə ðə stʃɹɔ ən mənʊɹ ən ɡeɪv ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ fɹaʊn ət ðə fɑɹmɝ, kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə bæk ə ðə bɑɹn wɪð ə bʌkəɾ ɪn wʌn hæn ən ɪz mɪlkɪŋ stul ɪn ði ʌðɝ. ə stupt oʊl mæn wɪð skɪn laɪk lɛðɝ ən θɪn, ɡɹeɪ hɛɹ, ðə fɑɹmɝ sloʊd wən i sɔ mæt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ðən lʊkt əweɪ kwɪkli ən hɝiɾ ɑn aʊɾ ə ðə bɑɹn, slɑpɪŋ mɪlk oʊvɝ ðə ɹɪm ə ðə bʌkəɾ ɪn ɪz heɪst.

Mat dug his hayfork into the straw and manure and gave a sidelong frown at the farmer, coming from the back of the barn with a bucket in one hand and his milking stool in the other. A stooped old man with skin like leather and thin, gray hair, the farmer slowed when he saw Mat looking at him, then looked away quickly and hurried on out of the barn, slopping milk over the rim of the bucket in his haste.

"hiz ʌp tə sʌmθɪŋ, aɪ tɛl ju," mæt sɛd. "si ðə weɪ hi wʊdn mit maɪ aɪ? waɪ ɑɹ ðeɪ soʊ fɹɛnli tə ə kʌpəl ʌv wɑndɝɝz ðeɪ nɛvɝ leɪɾ aɪz ɑn bɪfɔɹ? tɛl mi ðæt."

"He's up to something, I tell you," Mat said. "See the way he wouldn't meet my eye? Why are they so friendly to a couple of wanderers they never laid eyes on before? Tell me that."

"hɪz waɪf sɛz wi ɹimaɪn əɹ ə ðɛɹ ɡɹændsʌnz. wɪl jə stɑp wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt ðɛm? wʌt wɪv tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪz bɪhaɪn ʌs. aɪ hoʊp."

"His wife says we remind her of their grandsons. Will you stop worrying about them? What we have to worry about is behind us. I hope."

"hiz ʌp tə sʌmθɪŋ," mæt mʌɾɝd.

"He's up to something," Mat muttered.

wən ðeɪ fɪnɪʃt, ðeɪ wɑʃt ʌp ət ðə tʃɹɔf ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə bɑɹn, ðɛɹ ʃædoʊz stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ lɔŋ wɪð ðə sɪŋkɪŋ sʌn. ɹænd taʊəld ɔf wɪð ɪz ʃɝɾ əz ðeɪ wɔk tə ðə fɑɹmhaʊs. ðə fɑɹmɝ mɛɾ əm ət ðə dɔɹ; hi lin ɑn ə kɔɹɾɝstæf ɪn ə tu-kæʒəwəl mænɝ. bɪhaɪn ɪm ɪz waɪf klʌtʃt əɹ eɪpɹən ən pɪɹd pæst ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, tʃuɪŋ əɹ lɪp. ɹænd saɪd; hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i ən mæt ɹimaɪndəɾ əm ə ðɛɹ ɡɹændsʌnz ɛni lɔŋɡɝ.

When they finished, they washed up at the trough in front of the barn, their shadows stretching long with the sinking sun. Rand toweled off with his shirt as they walked to the farmhouse. The farmer met them at the door; he leaned on a quarterstaff in a too-casual manner. Behind him his wife clutched her apron and peered past his shoulder, chewing her lip. Rand sighed; he did not think he and Mat reminded them of their grandsons any longer.

"aʊɝ sʌnz ɑɹ kʌmɪŋ tə vɪzət tənaɪt," ði oʊl mæn sɛd. "ɔl fɔɹ ə ðɛm. aɪ fɝɡɑt. ðəɹ ɔl fɔɹ kʌmɪŋ. bɪɡ lædz. stʃɹɔŋ. bi hɪɹ ɛni taɪm, naʊ. aɪm əfɹeɪd wi doʊn əv ðə bɛd wi pɹɑməs ju."

"Our sons are coming to visit tonight," the old man said. "All four of them. I forgot. They're all four coming. Big lads. Strong. Be here any time, now. I'm afraid we don't have the bed we promised you."

hɪz waɪf θɹʌst ə smɔl bʌndəl ɹæpt ɪn ə næpkɪn pæs hɪm. "hɪɹ. ɪts bɹɛd, ən tʃiz, ən pɪkəlz, ən læm. ɪnʌf fəɹ tu milz, meɪbi. hɪɹ." hɝ ɹɪŋkəl feɪs æskt əm tə pliz teɪk ɪɾ ən ɡoʊ.

His wife thrust a small bundle wrapped in a napkin past him. "Here. It's bread, and cheese, and pickles, and lamb. Enough for two meals, maybe. Here." Her wrinkled face asked them to please take it and go.

ɹænd tʊk ðə bʌndəl. "θæŋk ju. aɪ ʌndɝstænd. kʌm ɑn, mæt."

Rand took the bundle. "Thank you. I understand. Come on, Mat."

mæt fɑloʊd hɪm, ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ waɪl i pʊld ɪz ʃɝɾ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. ɹænd θɔɾ ɪt bɛs tə kʌvɝ əz mɛni maɪlz əz ðeɪ kəd bɪfɔɹ stɑpɪŋ tə it. ði oʊl fɑɹmɝ hæɾ ə dɔɡ.

Mat followed him, grumbling while he pulled his shirt over his head. Rand thought it best to cover as many miles as they could before stopping to eat. The old farmer had a dog.

ɪt cʊɾə bɪn wɝs, hi θɔt. θɹi deɪz ɝliɝ, waɪl ðeɪ wɝ stɪl wɝkɪŋ, ðeɪd hæd ðə dɑɡz sɛɾ ɑn ðɛm. ðə dɑɡz, ən ðə fɑɹmɝ, ən ɪz tu sʌnz weɪvɪŋ kʌdʒəlz tʃeɪst əm aʊt tə ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊɾ ən hæf ə maɪl daʊn ɪt bɪfɔɹ ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp. ðeɪ hæd bɛɹli hæd taɪm tə snætʃ ʌp ðɛɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz ən ɹʌn. ðə fɑɹmɝ hæd kæɹiɾ ə baʊ wɪð ə bɹɔd-hɛɾ æɹoʊ nɑkt.

It could have been worse, he thought. Three days earlier, while they were still working, they'd had the dogs set on them. The dogs, and the farmer, and his two sons waving cudgels chased them out to the Caemlyn Road and half a mile down it before giving up. They had barely had time to snatch up their belongings and run. The farmer had carried a bow with a broad-head arrow nocked.

"doʊn kʌm bæk, hɪɹ!" hi hæd ʃaʊɾəd æftɝ ðɛm. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jəɹ ʌp tə, bʌt doʊn lemi si jəɹ ʃɪfti aɪz əɡɛn!"

"Don't come back, hear!" he had shouted after them. "I don't know what you're up to, but don't let me see your shifty eyes again!"

mæt hæd stɑɹɾəd tə tɝn bæk, fʌmbəlɪŋ əɾ ɪz kwɪvɝ, bʌt ɹænd pʊld ɪm ɑn. "ɑɹ jə kɹeɪzi?" mæt ɡeɪv ɪm ə sʌlən lʊk, bʌɾ ət list i kɛpt ɹʌnɪŋ.

Mat had started to turn back, fumbling at his quiver, but Rand pulled him on. "Are you crazy?" Mat gave him a sullen look, but at least he kept running.

ɹænd səmtaɪmz wʌndɝɾ ɪf ɪt wɑz wɝθwaɪl stɑpɪŋ ət fɑɹmz. ðə fɝðɝ ðeɪ wɛnt, ðə mɔɹ səspɪʃəs ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz mæt bɪkeɪm, ən ðə lɛs i wɑz eɪbəl tə haɪɾ ɪt. əɹ bɑðɝd tə. ðə milz ɡɑt skɪmpiɝ fəɹ ðə seɪm wɝk, ən səmtaɪmz nɑɾ ivən ðə bɑɹn wɑz ɔfɝɾ əz ə pleɪs tə slip. bʌt ðən ə səluʃən tə ɔl ðɛɹ pɹɑbləmz keɪm tə ɹænd, əɹ soʊ ɪt simd, ən ɪt keɪm ət ɡɹɪnwɛlz fɑɹm.

Rand sometimes wondered if it was worthwhile stopping at farms. The further they went, the more suspicious of strangers Mat became, and the less he was able to hide it. Or bothered to. The meals got skimpier for the same work, and sometimes not even the barn was offered as a place to sleep. But then a solution to all their problems came to Rand, or so it seemed, and it came at Grinwell's farm.

mæstɝ ɡɹɪnwɛl ən ɪz waɪf hæd naɪn tʃɪlʒɹən, ði ɛldəst ə dɔɾɝ nɑt mɔɹ ðən ə jɪɹ jʌŋɡɝ ðən ɹænd ən mæt. mæstɝ ɡɹɪnwɛl wɑz ə stɝɾi mæn, ən wɪð ɪz tʃɪlʒɹən i pɹɑbli hæd noʊ niɾ ʌv ɛni mɔɹ hɛlp, bʌɾ i lʊkt əm ʌp ən daʊn, teɪkɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ tʃɹævəl-steɪn kloʊðz ən dʌsti buts, ən əlaʊɾ əz haʊ hi kəɾ ɔlweɪz faɪnd wɝk fəɹ mɔɹ hænz. mɪstʃɹəs ɡɹɪnwɛl sɛd ðəɾ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə iɾ əɾ əɹ teɪbəl, ðeɪ wəd nɑt də ɪɾ ɪn ðoʊz fɪlθi θɪŋz. ʃi wɑz əbaʊt tə də lɔnʒɹi, ən səm ə hɝ hʌzbənz oʊl kloʊðz wəd fɪɾ əm wɛl ɪnʌf fəɹ wɝkɪŋ. ʃi smaɪld wən ʃi sɛɾ ɪt, ən fəɹ ə mɪnət ʃi lʊk tə ɹænd dʒʌs laɪk mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹ, ðoʊ hɝ hɛɹ wɑz jɛloʊ; hi hæd nɛvɝ sin hɛɹ ðət kʌlɝ bɪfɔɹ. ivən mæt sim tə luz səm ə hɪz tɛnʃən wən əɹ smaɪl tʌtʃt hɪm. ði ɛldəs dɔɾɝ wɑz ənʌðɝ mæɾɝ.

Master Grinwell and his wife had nine children, the eldest a daughter not more than a year younger than Rand and Mat. Master Grinwell was a sturdy man, and with his children he probably had no need of any more help, but he looked them up and down, taking in their travel-stained clothes and dusty boots, and allowed as how he could always find work for more hands. Mistress Grinwell said that if they were going to eat at her table, they would not do it in those filthy things. She was about to do laundry, and some of her husband's old clothes would fit them well enough for working. She smiled when she said it, and for a minute she looked to Rand just like Mistress al'Vere, though her hair was yellow; he had never seen hair that color before. Even Mat seemed to lose some of his tension when her smile touched him. The eldest daughter was another matter.

dɑɹk-hɛɹd, bɪɡ-aɪd, ən pɹɪɾi, ɛls ɡɹɪn ɪmpuɾəntli əɾ əm wɛnɛvɝ əɹ pɛɹəns wɝ nɑt lʊkɪŋ. waɪl ðeɪ wɝkt, muvɪŋ bæɹəlz ən sæks ʌv ɡɹeɪn ɪn ðə bɑɹn, ʃi hʌŋ oʊvɝ ə stɔl dɔɹ, hʌmɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf ən tʃuɪŋ ði ɛn ʌv wʌn lɔŋ pɪɡteɪl, wɑtʃɪŋ ðɛm. ɹænd ʃi wɑtʃt ɪspɛʃli. hi tʃɹaɪd tə ɪɡnɔɹ hɝ, bʌɾ æftɝ ə fju mɪnəts i pʊɾ ɑn ðə ʃɝt mæstɝ ɡɹɪnwɛl hæd loʊn hɪm. ɪt wɑz taɪɾ əkɹɔs ðə ʃoʊldɝz ən tu ʃɔɹt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz bɛɾɝ ðən nʌθɪŋ. ɛls læft aʊt laʊd wən i tʌɡd ɪɾ ɑn. hi bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk ðət ðɪs taɪm ɪt wəd nɑt bi mæts fɔlt wən ðeɪ wɝ tʃeɪst ɔf.

Dark-haired, big-eyed, and pretty, Else grinned impudently at them whenever her parents were not looking. While they worked, moving barrels and sacks of grain in the barn, she hung over a stall door, humming to herself and chewing the end of one long pigtail, watching them. Rand she watched especially. He tried to ignore her, but after a few minutes he put on the shirt Master Grinwell had loaned him. It was tight across the shoulders and too short, but it was better than nothing. Else laughed out loud when he tugged it on. He began to think that this time it would not be Mat's fault when they were chased off.

pɛɹɪn wəd noʊ haʊ tə hændəl ðɪs, hi θɔt. hid meɪk səm ɔfhæn kɑmɛnt, ən pɹɪɾi sun ʃid bi læfɪŋ əɾ ɪz dʒoʊks ɪnstɛɾ ə munɪŋ ɝaʊnd wɛɹ əɹ fɑðɝ kən si. oʊnli hi kəd nɑt θɪŋk ʌv ɛni ɔfhæn kɑmɛnt, əɹ ɛni dʒoʊks, iðɝ. wɛnɛvɝ i lʊkt ɪn əɹ dɝɛkʃən, ʃi smaɪld əɾ ɪm ɪn ə weɪ ðət wəɾ əv əɹ fɑðɝ lusɪŋ ðə dɑɡz ɑn əm ɪf i sɔ. wʌns ʃi toʊld ɪm ʃi laɪk tɔl mɛn. ɔl ðə bɔɪz ɑn ðə fɑɹmz ɝaʊn ðəɹ wɝ ʃɔɹt. mæt ɡeɪv ə næsti snɪkɝ. wɪʃɪŋ i kəd θɪŋk ʌv ə dʒoʊk, ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ɪz heɪfɔɹk.

Perrin would know how to handle this, he thought. He'd make some offhand comment, and pretty soon she'd be laughing at his jokes instead of mooning around where her father can see. Only he could not think of any offhand comment, or any jokes, either. Whenever he looked in her direction, she smiled at him in a way that would have her father loosing the dogs on them if he saw. Once she told him she liked tall men. All the boys on the farms around there were short. Mat gave a nasty snicker. Wishing he could think of a joke, Rand tried to concentrate on his hayfork.

ðə jʌŋɡɝ tʃɪlʒɹən, ət list, wɝ ə blɛsɪŋ ɪn ɹændz aɪz. mæts wɛɹinɪs ɔlweɪz izd ə lɪɾəl wən ðəɹ wɝ tʃɪlʒɹən ɝaʊnd. æftɝ sʌpɝ ðeɪ ɔl sɛɾəld ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs, wɪð mæstɝ ɡɹɪnwɛl ɪn ɪz feɪvɹɪt tʃɛɹ θʌmɪŋ ɪz paɪp fʊl ə təbæk ən mɪstʃɹəs ɡɹɪnwɛl fʌsɪŋ wɪð əɹ soʊɪŋ bɑks ən ðə ʃɝts ʃi hæd wɑʃt fəɹ ɪm ən mæt. mæt dʌɡ aʊt tɑmz kʌlɝd bɔlz ən bɪɡæn tə dʒʌɡəl. hi nɛvɝ dɪd ðəɾ ənlɛs ðəɹ wɝ tʃɪlʒɹən. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən læft wən i pɹitɛndəd tə bi dʒɹɑpɪŋ ðə bɔlz, snætʃɪŋ əm ət ðə læs mɪnət, ən ðeɪ klæp fəɹ faʊntənz ən fɪɡjɝ-eɪts ən ə sɪks-bɔl sɝkəl ðəɾ i ɹɪli dɪɾ ɔlmoʊs dʒɹɑp. bʌt ðeɪ tʊk ɪɾ ɪn ɡʊd pɑɹt, mæstɝ ɡɹɪnwɛl ən ɪz waɪf əplɔɾɪŋ əz hɑɹɾ əz ðɛɹ tʃɪlʒɹən. wən mæt wɑz dʌn, boʊɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə ɹum wɪð əz mɛni flɝɪʃəz əz tɑm maɪɾ əv meɪd, ɹænd tʊk tɑmz flut fɹəm ɪts keɪs.

The younger children, at least, were a blessing in Rand's eyes. Mat's wariness always eased a little when there were children around. After supper they all settled in front of the fireplace, with Master Grinwell in his favorite chair thumbing his pipe full of tabac and Mistress Grinwell fussing with her sewing box and the shirts she had washed for him and Mat. Mat dug out Thom's colored balls and began to juggle. He never did that unless there were children. The children laughed when he pretended to be dropping the balls, snatching them at the last minute, and they clapped for fountains and figure-eights and a six-ball circle that he really did almost drop. But they took it in good part, Master Grinwell and his wife applauding as hard as their children. When Mat was done, bowing around the room with as many flourishes as Thom might have made, Rand took Thom's flute from its case.

hi kəd nɛvɝ hændəl ði ɪnstʃɹəmənt wɪθaʊɾ ə pæŋ ə sædnəs. tʌtʃɪŋ ɪts ɡoʊld-ænd-sɪlvɝ skɹɑlwɝk wɑz laɪk tʌtʃɪŋ tɑmz mɛmɹi. hi nɛvɝ hændəl ðə hɑɹp ɪksɛp tə si ðəɾ ɪt wɑz seɪf ən dʒɹaɪ - tɑm hæɾ ɔlweɪz sɛd ðə hɑɹp wɑz bɪɑn ə fɑɹmbɔɪz klʌmzi hænz - bʌt wɛnɛvɝ ə fɑɹmɝ əlaʊɾ əm tə steɪ, hi ɔlweɪz pleɪd wʌn tun ɑn ðə fluɾ æftɝ sʌpɝ. ɪt wɑz dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl sʌmθɪŋ ɛkstʃɹə tə peɪ ðə fɑɹmɝ, ən meɪbi ə weɪ ʌv kipɪŋ tɑmz mɛmɹi fɹɛʃ.

He could never handle the instrument without a pang of sadness. Touching its gold-and-silver scrollwork was like touching Thom's memory. He never handled the harp except to see that it was safe and dry - Thom had always said the harp was beyond a farmboy's clumsy hands - but whenever a farmer allowed them to stay, he always played one tune on the flute after supper. It was just a little something extra to pay the farmer, and maybe a way of keeping Thom's memory fresh.

wɪð ə læfɪŋ muɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sɛt baɪ mæts dʒʌɡəlɪŋ, hi pleɪd "θɹi ɡɝlz ɪn ðə mɛdoʊ." mæstɝ ən mɪstʃɹəs ɡɹɪnwɛl klæpt əlɔŋ, ən ðə smɔlɝ tʃɪlʒɹən dænst ɝaʊn ðə flɔɹ, ivən ðə smɔləs bɔɪ, hu kəd bɛɹli wɔk, stɑmpɪŋ ɪz fiɾ ɪn taɪm. hi nu hi wəd wɪn noʊ pɹaɪzəz ət bɛl taɪn, bʌɾ æftɝ tɑmz titʃɪŋ i wəd nɑt bi ɪmbɛɹəs tə ɛntɝ.

With a laughing mood already set by Mat's juggling, he played "Three Girls in the Meadow." Master and Mistress Grinwell clapped along, and the smaller children danced around the floor, even the smallest boy, who could barely walk, stomping his feet in time. He knew he would win no prizes at Bel Tine, but after Thom's teaching he would not be embarrassed to enter.

ɛls wɑz sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝ, ən əz i loʊɝd ðə fluɾ æftɝ ðə læs noʊt, ʃi lin fɔɹwɝd wɪð ə lɔŋ saɪ ən smaɪld ət hɪm. "ju pleɪ soʊ bjuɾəfli. aɪ nɛvɝ hɝɾ ɛniθɪŋ soʊ bjuɾəfəl."

Else was sitting cross-legged in front of the fire, and as he lowered the flute after the last note, she leaned forward with a long sigh and smiled at him. "You play so beautifully. I never heard anything so beautiful."

mɪstʃɹəs ɡɹɪnwɛl sʌɾənli pɔzd ɪn əɹ soʊɪŋ ən ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ əɾ əɹ dɔɾɝ, ðən ɡeɪv ɹænd ə lɔŋ, əpɹeɪzɪŋ lʊk.

Mistress Grinwell suddenly paused in her sewing and raised an eyebrow at her daughter, then gave Rand a long, appraising look.

hi hæd pɪkt ʌp ðə lɛðɝ keɪs tə pʊt ðə fluɾ əweɪ, bʌɾ ʌndɝ əɹ stɛɹ i dʒɹɑp ðə keɪs ən ɔlmoʊs ðə flut, tu. ɪf ʃi əkjuzd ɪm ə tʃɹaɪflɪŋ wɪð əɹ dɔɾɝ. . . . ɪn dɛspɝeɪʃən i pʊt ðə flut bæk tə hɪz lɪps ən pleɪɾ ənʌðɝ sɔŋ, ðən ənʌðɝ, ən ənʌðɝ. mɪstʃɹəs ɡɹɪnwɛl kɛpt wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm. hi pleɪd "ðə wɪn ðət ʃeɪks ðə wɪloʊ," ən "kʌmɪŋ hoʊm fɹəm tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp," ən "mɪstʃɹəs eɪnɹəz ɹustɝ," ən "ði oʊl blæk bɛɹ." hi pleɪɾ ɛvɹi sɔŋ i kəd θɪŋk ʌv, bʌt ʃi nɛvɝ tʊk əɹ aɪz ɔf hɪm. ʃi nɛvɝ sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ, iðɝ, bʌt ʃi wɑtʃt, ən weɪd.

He had picked up the leather case to put the flute away, but under her stare he dropped the case and almost the flute, too. If she accused him of trifling with her daughter. . . . In desperation he put the flute back to his lips and played another song, then another, and another. Mistress Grinwell kept watching him. He played "The Wind That Shakes the Willow," and "Coming Home From Tarwin's Gap," and "Mistress Aynora's Rooster," and "The Old Black Bear." He played every song he could think of, but she never took her eyes off him. She never said anything, either, but she watched, and weighed.

ɪt wɑz leɪt wən mæstɝ ɡɹɪnwɛl faɪnəli stʊɾ ʌp, tʃʌklɪŋ ən ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ. "wɛl, ðɪs əz bɪn ɹɛɹ fʌn, bʌɾ ɪts weɪ pæst əɹ bɛdtaɪm. jə tʃɹævlɪŋ lædz meɪk jəɹ oʊn aʊɝz, bʌt mɔɹnɪŋ kʌmz ɝli ɑn ə fɑɹm. əl tɛl jə lædz, aɪ hæv peɪd ɡʊd mʌni əɾ ən ɪn fəɹ noʊ bɛɾɝ ɛntɝteɪnmən ðən aɪv hæd ðɪs naɪt. fəɹ wɝs."

It was late when Master Grinwell finally stood up, chuckling and rubbing his hands together. "Well, this has been rare fun, but it's way past our bedtime. You traveling lads make your own hours, but morning comes early on a farm. I'll tell you lads, I have paid good money at an inn for no better entertainment than I've had this night. For worse."

"aɪ θɪŋk ðeɪ ʃəɾ əv ə ɹɪwɔɹd, fɑðɝ," mɪstʃɹəs ɡɹɪnwɛl sɛɾ əz ʃi pɪkt ʌp əɹ jʌŋɡəs bɔɪ, hu hæd lɔŋ sɪns fɔlən əslip ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝ. "ðə bɑɹn ɪz noʊ fɪt pleɪs tə slip. ðeɪ kən slip ɪn ɛlsəz ɹum tənaɪt, ən ʃɪl slip wɪð mi."

"I think they should have a reward, father," Mistress Grinwell said as she picked up her youngest boy, who had long since fallen asleep in front of the fire. "The barn is no fit place to sleep. They can sleep in Else's room tonight, and she will sleep with me."

ɛls ɡɹɪməst. ʃi wɑz kɛɹfəl tə kip əɹ hɛd daʊn, bʌt ɹænd sɔ ɪt. hi θɔɾ əɹ mʌðɝ dɪd, tu.

Else grimaced. She was careful to keep her head down, but Rand saw it. He thought her mother did, too.

mæstɝ ɡɹɪnwɛl nɑɾəd. "jɛs, jɛs, mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðən ðə bɑɹn. ɪf jə doʊn maɪn slipɪŋ tu tə ə bɛd, ðəɾ ɪz." ɹænd flʌʃt; mɪstʃɹəs ɡɹɪnwɛl wɑz stɪl lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. "aɪ də wɪʃ aɪ kəd hɪɹ mɔɹ ə ðət flut. ən jəɹ dʒʌɡəlɪŋ, tu. aɪ laɪk ðæt. jə noʊ, ðɛɹz ə lɪɾəl tæsk jə kəd hɛlp wɪð təmɑɹoʊ, ən - "

Master Grinwell nodded. "Yes, yes, much better than the barn. If you don't mind sleeping two to a bed, that is." Rand flushed; Mistress Grinwell was still looking at him. "I do wish I could hear more of that flute. And your juggling, too. I like that. You know, there's a little task you could help with tomorrow, and - "

"ðeɪl bi wɑntɪŋ ən ɝli stɑɹt, fɑðɝ," mɪstʃɹəs ɡɹɪnwɛl kʌɾ ɪn. "ɛɹin ɪz ðə nɛks vɪlədʒ ðə weɪ ðəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ, ən ɪf ðeɪ ɪntɛn tə tʃɹaɪ ðɛɹ lʌk ət ði ɪn ðɛɹ, ðəl əv tə wɔk ɔl deɪ tə ɡɛt ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ dɑɹk."

"They'll be wanting an early start, father," Mistress Grinwell cut in. "Arien is the next village the way they're going, and if they intend to try their luck at the inn there, they'll have to walk all day to get there before dark."

"jɛs, mɪstʃɹəs," ɹænd sɛd, "wi wɪl. ən θæŋk ju."

"Yes, mistress," Rand said, "we will. And thank you."

ʃi ɡeɪv ɪm ə taɪt-lɪp smaɪl əz ɪf ʃi nu vɛɹi wɛl ðəɾ ɪz θæŋks wɝ fəɹ mɔɹ ðən əɹ ædvaɪs, əɹ ivən sʌpɝ ən ə wɔɹm bɛd.

She gave him a tight-lipped smile as if she knew very well that his thanks were for more than her advice, or even supper and a warm bed.

ðə hoʊl nɛks deɪ mæt twɪɾɪd ɪm əbaʊɾ ɛls əz ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ daʊn ðə ɹoʊd. hi kɛp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə sʌbʒɪkt, ən wʌt ðə ɡɹɪnwɛlz hæd sədʒɛstəɾ əbaʊt pɝfɔɹmɪŋ əɾ ɪnz wɑz ði iziəs θɪŋ tə maɪnd. ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, wɪð ɛls paʊɾɪŋ əz i lɛft, ən mɪstʃɹəs ɡɹɪnwɛl wɑtʃɪŋ wɪð ə ʃɑɹp-aɪd lʊk ʌv ɡʊd-ɹɪɾəns ən sunəst-mɛndɪd, ɪt wɑz dʒʌst sʌmθɪŋ tə kip mæt fɹəm tɔkɪŋ. baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ dɪd ɹitʃ ðə nɛks vɪlədʒ, ɪt wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɛls əɡɛn.
