The whole next day Mat twitted him about Else as they made their way down the road. He kept trying to change the subject, and what the Grinwells had suggested about performing at inns was the easiest thing to mind. In the morning, with Else pouting as he left, and Mistress Grinwell watching with a sharp-eyed look of good-riddance and soonest-mended, it was just something to keep Mat from talking. By the time they did reach the next village, it was something else again.

wɪð dʌsk dɪsɛndɪŋ, ðeɪ ɛntɝd ði oʊnli ɪn ɪn ɛɹin, ən ɹænd spoʊk tə ði ɪnkipɝ. hi pleɪd "fɛɹi ɝ ðə ɹɪvɝ" - wɪtʃ ðə plʌmp ɪnkipɝ kɔld "dɑɹlɪŋ sɛɹə" - ən pɑɹɾ ʌv "ðə ɹoʊd tə dʌn ɹɛn," ən mæt dɪɾ ə lɪɾəl dʒʌɡəlɪŋ, ən ði ʌpʃɑt wɑz ðət ðeɪ slɛpt ɪn ə bɛd ðət naɪɾ ən eɪt ɹoʊstəd pəteɪɾoʊz ən hɑt bif. ɪt wɑz ðə smɔləst ɹum ɪn ði ɪn, tə bi ʃʊɹ, ʌp ʌndɝ ði ivz ɪn ðə bæk, ən ðə mil keɪm ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə lɔŋ naɪɾ ə pleɪɪŋ ən dʒʌɡəlɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl ə bɛd bɪniθ ə ɹuf. ivən bɛɾɝ, tə ɹænd, ɛvɹi deɪlaɪɾ aʊɝ hæd bɪn spɛn tʃɹævlɪŋ. ən ði ɪnz peɪtʃɹənz dɪd nɑt sim tə kɛɹ ɪf mæt stɛɹɾ əɾ əm səspɪʃəsli. səm ə ðɛm ivən lʊkt əskæns ət wʌn ənʌðɝ. ðə taɪmz meɪd səspɪʃən ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz ə kɑmənpleɪs, ən ðəɹ wɝ ɔlweɪz stʃɹeɪnʒɝz əɾ ən ɪn.

With dusk descending, they entered the only inn in Arien, and Rand spoke to the innkeeper. He played "Ferry O'er the River" - which the plump innkeeper called "Darling Sara" - and part of "The Road to Dun Aren," and Mat did a little juggling, and the upshot was that they slept in a bed that night and ate roasted potatoes and hot beef. It was the smallest room in the inn, to be sure, up under the eaves in the back, and the meal came in the middle of a long night of playing and juggling, but it was still a bed beneath a roof. Even better, to Rand, every daylight hour had been spent traveling. And the inn's patrons did not seem to care if Mat stared at them suspiciously. Some of them even looked askance at one another. The times made suspicion of strangers a commonplace, and there were always strangers at an inn.

ɹænd slɛp bɛɾɝ ðən i hæd sɪns livɪŋ waɪtbɹɪdʒ, dɪspaɪt ʃɛɹɪŋ ə bɛd wɪð mæt ən ɪz nɑktɝnəl mʌɾɝɪŋ. ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ði ɪnkipɝ tʃɹaɪd tə tɔk əm ɪndə steɪɪŋ ənʌðɝ deɪ əɹ tu, bʌt wən i kəd nɑt, hi kɔld oʊvɝ ə blɪɹi-aɪd fɑɹmɝ u hæd dʒɹʌŋk tu mʌtʃ tə dʒɹaɪv ɪz kɑɹt hoʊm ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ. ən aʊɝ leɪɾɝ ðeɪ wɝ faɪv maɪlz fɝðɝ ist, spɹɔlɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ bæks ɑn ðə stʃɹɔ ɪn ðə bæk ʌv izəl fɔɹniz kɑɹt.

Rand slept better than he had since leaving Whitebridge, despite sharing a bed with Mat and his nocturnal muttering. In the morning the innkeeper tried to talk them into staying another day or two, but when he could not, he called over a bleary-eyed farmer who had drunk too much to drive his cart home the night before. An hour later they were five miles further east, sprawling on their backs on the straw in the back of Eazil Forney's cart.

ðət bɪkeɪm ðə weɪ ʌv ðɛɹ tʃɹævlɪŋ. wɪð ə lɪɾəl lʌk, ən meɪbi ə ɹaɪɾ əɹ tu, ðeɪ kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz ɹitʃ ðə nɛks vɪlədʒ baɪ dɑɹk. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ ðən wʌn ɪn ɪn ə vɪlədʒ, ði ɪnkipɝz wəd bɪd fəɹ əm wʌns ðeɪ hɝd ɹændz fluɾ ən sɔ mæt dʒʌɡəl. təɡɛðɝ ðeɪ stɪl dɪd nɑt kʌm kloʊs tə ə ɡlimən, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ mɔɹ ðən moʊs vɪlədʒəz sɔ ɪn ə jɪɹ. tu əɹ θɹi ɪnz ɪn ə taʊn mɛn ə bɛɾɝ ɹum, wɪð tu bɛdz, ən mɔɹ dʒɛnɝəs pɔɹʃənz ʌv ə bɛɾɝ kʌɾ ə mit, ən səmtaɪmz ivən ə fju kɑpɝz ɪn ðɛɹ pɑkəts wən ðeɪ lɛf bɪsaɪdz. ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋz ðəɹ wɑz ɔlmoʊst ɔlweɪz sʌmwʌn tə ɔfɝ ə ɹaɪd, ənʌðɝ fɑɹmɝ u hæd steɪd tu leɪɾ ən dʒɹʌŋk tu mʌtʃ, əɹ ə mɝtʃən u hæd laɪk ðɛɹ ɛntɝteɪnmən ɪnʌf nɑt tə maɪn ɪf ðeɪ hɑpt ʌp ɑn ðə bæk ʌv wʌn ə hɪz wæɡənz. ɹænd bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk ðɛɹ pɹɑbləmz wɝ oʊvɝ tɪl ðeɪ ɹitʃt keɪɛmlɪn. bʌt ðən ðeɪ keɪm tə fɔɹ kɪŋz.

That became the way of their traveling. With a little luck, and maybe a ride or two, they could almost always reach the next village by dark. If there was more than one inn in a village, the innkeepers would bid for them once they heard Rand's flute and saw Mat juggle. Together they still did not come close to a gleeman, but they were more than most villages saw in a year. Two or three inns in a town meant a better room, with two beds, and more generous portions of a better cut of meat, and sometimes even a few coppers in their pockets when they left besides. In the mornings there was almost always someone to offer a ride, another farmer who had stayed too late and drunk too much, or a merchant who had liked their entertainment enough not to mind if they hopped up on the back of one of his wagons. Rand began to think their problems were over till they reached Caemlyn. But then they came to Four Kings.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾitu


CHAPTER 32

fɔɹ kɪŋz ɪn ʃædoʊ


Four Kings in Shadow

ðə vɪlədʒ wɑz bɪɡɝ ðən moʊst, bʌt stɪl ə skɹʌfi taʊn tə bɛɹ ə neɪm laɪk fɔɹ kɪŋz. əz juʒəwəl, ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd ɹæn stʃɹeɪt θɹu ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə taʊn, bʌɾ ənʌðɝ hɛvəli tʃɹævəl haɪweɪ keɪm ɪn fɹəm ðə saʊθ, tu. moʊs vɪlədʒəz wɝ mɑɹkəts ən ɡæðɝɪŋ pleɪsəz fəɹ ðə fɑɹmɝz ə ði ɛɹiə, bʌt ðəɹ wɝ fju fɑɹmɝz tə bi sin hɪɹ. fɔɹ kɪŋz sɝvaɪvd əz ə stɑpoʊvɝ fəɹ mɝtʃəns' wæɡən tʃɹeɪnz ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn ən tə ðə maɪnɪŋ taʊnz ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪs bɪɑn bɛɹlən, əz wɛl əz ðə vɪlədʒəz bɪtwin. ðə sʌðɝn ɹoʊd kæɹid luɡɹdz tʃɹeɪd wɪð ðə maɪnz ɪn ðə wɛst; luɡɑɝɾɝ mɝtʃəns ɡoʊɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn hæɾ ə mɔɹ dɝɛkt ɹut. ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ kʌntʃɹi hɛl fju fɑɹmz, bɛɹli ɪnʌf tə fid ðɛmsɛlvz ən ðə taʊn, ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ sɛntɝɾ ɑn ðə mɝtʃəns ən ðɛɹ wæɡənz, ðə mɛn u dʒɹoʊv əm ən ðə leɪbɝɝz u loʊɾəd ðə ɡʊdz.

The village was bigger than most, but still a scruffy town to bear a name like Four Kings. As usual, the Caemlyn Road ran straight through the center of the town, but another heavily traveled highway came in from the south, too. Most villages were markets and gathering places for the farmers of the area, but there were few farmers to be seen here. Four Kings survived as a stopover for merchants' wagon trains on their way to Caemlyn and to the mining towns in the Mountains of Mist beyond Baerlon, as well as the villages between. The southern road carried Lugard's trade with the mines in the west; Lugarder merchants going to Caemlyn had a more direct route. The surrounding country held few farms, barely enough to feed themselves and the town, and everything in the village centered on the merchants and their wagons, the men who drove them and the laborers who loaded the goods.

plɑts ə bɛɹ ɝθ, ɡɹaʊn tə dʌst, leɪ skæɾɝd θɹu fɔɹ kɪŋz, fɪld wɪð wæɡənz pɑɹkt wil tə wil ən əbændən ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju bɔɹd ɡɑɹdz. steɪbəlz ən hɔɹs-lɑts laɪn ðə stʃɹits, ɔl ʌv wɪtʃ wɝ waɪɾ ɪnʌf tə əlaʊ wæɡənz tə pæs ən dipli ɹʌɾɪd fɹəm tu mɛni wilz. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ vɪlədʒ ɡɹin, ən ðə tʃɪlʒɹən pleɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹʌts, dɑdʒɪŋ wæɡənz ən ðə kɝsɪz ʌv wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz. vɪlədʒ wɪmən, ðɛɹ hɛdz kʌvɝd wɪð skɑɹvz, kɛp ðɛɹ aɪz daʊn ən wɔkt kwɪkli, səmtaɪmz fɑloʊd baɪ wæɡənɪɹz' kɑmɛns ðət meɪd ɹænd blʌʃ; ivən mæt ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ət səm ə ðɛm. noʊ wʊmən stʊd ɡɑsəpɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə fɛns wɪð ə neɪbɝ. dʒɹæb wʊɾən haʊsəz stʊd tʃik baɪ dʒaʊl, wɪð oʊnli nɛɹoʊ æliz bɪtwin ən waɪtwɑʃ - wɛɹ ɛniwʌn hæd bɑðɝd tə waɪtwɑʃ ðə wɛðɝd bɔɹdz - feɪɾəd əz ɪf ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn fɹɛʃən ɪn jɪɹz. hɛvi ʃʌɾɝz ɑn ðə haʊsəz hæd nɑt bɪn oʊpən ɪn soʊ lɔŋ ðət ðə hɪnʒɪz wɝ sɑləd lʌmps ə ɹʌst. nɔɪz hʌŋ oʊvɝ ɛvɹiθɪŋ, klæŋɪŋ fɹəm blæksmɪθs, ʃaʊts fɹəm ðə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz, ɹɔkəs læftɝ fɹəm ðə taʊnz ɪnz.

Plots of bare earth, ground to dust, lay scattered through Four Kings, filled with wagons parked wheel to wheel and abandoned except for a few bored guards. Stables and horse-lots lined the streets, all of which were wide enough to allow wagons to pass and deeply rutted from too many wheels. There was no village green, and the children played in the ruts, dodging wagons and the curses of wagon drivers. Village women, their heads covered with scarves, kept their eyes down and walked quickly, sometimes followed by wagoneers' comments that made Rand blush; even Mat gave a start at some of them. No woman stood gossiping over the fence with a neighbor. Drab wooden houses stood cheek by jowl, with only narrow alleys between and whitewash - where anyone had bothered to whitewash the weathered boards - faded as if it had not been freshened in years. Heavy shutters on the houses had not been open in so long that the hinges were solid lumps of rust. Noise hung over everything, clanging from blacksmiths, shouts from the wagon drivers, raucous laughter from the town's inns.

ɹænd swʌŋ daʊn fɹəm ðə bæk ʌv ə mɝtʃəns kænvəs-tɑpt wæɡən əz ðeɪ keɪm əbɹɛst ʌv ə ɡɛɹɪʃli peɪntəɾ ɪn, ɔl ɡɹinz ən jɛloʊz ðət kɑt ði aɪ fɹəm əfɑɹ əmʌŋ ðə lɛɾən haʊzɪz. ðə laɪn ʌv wæɡənz kɛp muvɪŋ. nʌn ə ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz ivən sim tə noʊɾəs ðəɾ i ən mæt hæd ɡɔn; dʌsk wɑz fɔlɪŋ, ən ðeɪ ɔl hæd ðɛɹ aɪz ɑn ənhɪtʃɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz ən ɹitʃɪŋ ði ɪnz. ɹænd stʌmbəld ɪn ə ɹʌt, ðən lɛp kwɪkli tə əvɔɪɾ ə hɛvi-leɪɾən wæɡən klæɾɝɪŋ ði ʌðɝ weɪ. ðə dʒɹaɪvɝ ʃaʊɾəd ə kɝs əɾ ɪm əz ðə wæɡən ɹoʊl baɪ. ə vɪlədʒ wʊmən stɛpt ɝaʊn ɪm ən hɝiɾ ɑn wɪθaʊɾ ɛvɝ miɾɪŋ ɪz aɪ.

Rand swung down from the back of a merchant's canvas-topped wagon as they came abreast of a garishly painted inn, all greens and yellows that caught the eye from afar among the leaden houses. The line of wagons kept moving. None of the drivers even seemed to notice that he and Mat had gone; dusk was falling, and they all had their eyes on unhitching the horses and reaching the inns. Rand stumbled in a rut, then leaped quickly to avoid a heavy-laden wagon clattering the other way. The driver shouted a curse at him as the wagon rolled by. A village woman stepped around him and hurried on without ever meeting his eye.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ əbaʊt ðɪs pleɪs," hi sɛd. hi θɔɾ i kəd hɪɹ mjuzɪk mɪkst ɪn ðə dɪn, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt tɛl fɹəm wɛɹ ɪt wɑz kʌmɪŋ. fɹəm ði ɪn, meɪbi, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz hɑɹd tə bi ʃʊɹ. "aɪ doʊn laɪk ɪt. meɪbi wid bɛɾɝ ɡoʊ ɑn ðɪs taɪm."

"I don't know about this place," he said. He thought he could hear music mixed in the din, but he could not tell from where it was coming. From the inn, maybe, but it was hard to be sure. "I don't like it. Maybe we'd better go on this time."

mæt ɡeɪv ɪm ə skɔɹnfəl lʊk, ðən ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz ət ðə skaɪ. dɑɹk klaʊdz θɪkən oʊvɝhɛd. "æn slip ʌndɝ ə hɛdʒ tənaɪt? ɪn ðæt? aɪm juz tə ə bɛɾ əɡɛn." hi kɑkt ɪz hɛd tə lɪsən, ðən ɡɹʌntɪd. "meɪbi wʌn ə ðiz pleɪsəz dʌzn əv mjuzɪʃənz. ɛniweɪ, əl bɛt ðeɪ doʊn əv ə dʒʌɡəlɝ." hi slʌŋ ɪz baʊ əkɹɔs ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən stɑɹɾəd fəɹ ðə bɹaɪt jɛloʊ dɔɹ, stʌɾiɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ θɹu nɛɹoʊɾ aɪz. ɹænd fɑloʊd daʊtfəli.

Mat gave him a scornful look, then rolled his eyes at the sky. Dark clouds thickened overhead. "And sleep under a hedge tonight? In that? I'm used to a bed again." He cocked his head to listen, then grunted. "Maybe one of these places doesn't have musicians. Anyway, I'll bet they don't have a juggler." He slung his bow across his shoulders and started for the bright yellow door, studying everything through narrowed eyes. Rand followed doubtfully.

ðəɹ wɝ mjuzɪʃənz ɪnsaɪd, ðɛɹ zɪðɝ ən dʒɹʌm ɔlmoʊs dʒɹaʊn ɪn kɔɹs læftɝ ən dʒɹʌŋkən ʃaʊɾɪŋ. ɹænd dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə faɪn ðə lændlɔɹd. ðə nɛks tu ɪnz hæd mjuzɪʃənz əz wɛl, ən ðə seɪm dɛfənɪŋ kækɑfəni. ɹʌfli dʒɹɛs mɛn fɪl ðə teɪbəlz ən stʌmbəld əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ, weɪvɪŋ mʌɡz ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə fɑndəl sɝvɪŋ meɪdz u dɑdʒd wɪð fɪkst, lɔŋ-sʌfɝɪŋ smaɪlz. ðə bɪldɪŋz ʃʊk wɪð ðə ɹækɪt, ən ðə smɛl wɑz saʊɝ, ə stɛntʃ ʌv oʊld waɪn ən ənwɑʃt bɑɾiz. ʌv ðə mɝtʃəns, ɪn ðɛɹ sɪlk ən vɛlvəɾ ən leɪs, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn; pɹaɪvət daɪnɪŋ ɹumz əbʌvstɛɹz pɹətɛktəd ðɛɹ ɪɹz ən noʊzɪz. hi ən mæt oʊnli pʊt ðɛɹ hɛdz ɪn ðə dɔɹz bɪfɔɹ livɪŋ. hi wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə θɪŋk ðeɪ wəɾ əv noʊ tʃɔɪs bʌt tə muv ɑn.

There were musicians inside, their zither and drum almost drowned in coarse laughter and drunken shouting. Rand did not bother to find the landlord. The next two inns had musicians as well, and the same deafening cacophony. Roughly dressed men filled the tables and stumbled across the floor, waving mugs and trying to fondle serving maids who dodged with fixed, long-suffering smiles. The buildings shook with the racket, and the smell was sour, a stench of old wine and unwashed bodies. Of the merchants, in their silk and velvet and lace, there was no sign; private dining rooms abovestairs protected their ears and noses. He and Mat only put their heads in the doors before leaving. He was beginning to think they would have no choice but to move on.

ðə fɔɹθ ɪn, ðə dænsɪŋ kɑɹtmən, stʊd saɪlənt.

The fourth inn, The Dancing Cartman, stood silent.

ɪt wɑz əz ɡɔɾi əz ði ʌðɝ ɪnz, jɛloʊ tʃɹɪmd ɪn bɹaɪt ɹɛɾ ən bɪliəs, aɪ-ɹɛntʃɪŋ ɡɹin, ðoʊ hɪɹ ðə peɪnt wɑz kɹækt ən pilɪŋ. ɹænd ən mæt stɛpt ɪnsaɪd.

It was as gaudy as the other inns, yellow trimmed in bright red and bilious, eye-wrenching green, though here the paint was cracked and peeling. Rand and Mat stepped inside.

oʊnli hæf ə dʌzən mɛn sæɾ ət ðə teɪbəlz ðət fɪl ðə kɑmən ɹum, hʌntʃt oʊvɝ ðɛɹ mʌɡz, itʃ wʌn ɡlʌmli əloʊn wɪð ɪz θɔts. bɪznəs wɑz dɛfənətli nɑt ɡʊd, bʌɾ ɪt hæd bɪn bɛɾɝ wʌns. ɪɡzækli əz mɛni sɝvɪŋ meɪdz əz ðəɹ wɝ peɪtʃɹənz bɪzid ðɛmsɛlvz ɝaʊn ðə ɹum. ðəɹ wɑz plɛnti fəɹ əm tə də - dɝt kɹʌstɪd ðə flɔɹ ən kɑbwɛbz fɪl ðə kɔɹnɝz ə ðə silɪŋ - bʌt moʊst wɝ nɑt duɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ ɹɪli jusfəl, oʊnli muvɪŋ soʊ ðeɪ wəd nɑt bi sin stændɪŋ stɪl.

Only half a dozen men sat at the tables that filled the common room, hunched over their mugs, each one glumly alone with his thoughts. Business was definitely not good, but it had been better once. Exactly as many serving maids as there were patrons busied themselves around the room. There was plenty for them to do - dirt crusted the floor and cobwebs filled the corners of the ceiling - but most were not doing anything really useful, only moving so they would not be seen standing still.

ə boʊni mæn wɪð lɔŋ, stʃɹɪŋi hɛɹ tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz tɝn tə skaʊl əɾ əm əz ðeɪ keɪm θɹu ðə dɔɹ. ðə fɝst sloʊ pil ə θʌndɝ ɹʌmbəld əkɹɔs fɔɹ kɪŋz. "wʌt dʒju wɑnt?" hi wɑz ɹʌbɪŋ ɪz hænz ɑn ə ɡɹisi eɪpɹən ðət hʌŋ tə hɪz æŋkəlz. ɹænd wʌndɝɾ ɪf mɔɹ ɡɹaɪm wɑz kʌmɪŋ ɔf ɑn ði eɪpɹən əɹ ɑn ðə mænz hænz. hi wɑz ðə fɝst skɪni ɪnkipɝ ɹænd hæd sin. "wɛl? spik ʌp, baɪ ə dʒɹɪŋk, əɹ ɡɛɾ aʊt! də aɪ lʊk laɪk ə ɹɝi ʃoʊ?"

A bony man with long, stringy hair to his shoulders turned to scowl at them as they came through the door. The first slow peal of thunder rumbled across Four Kings. "What do you want?" He was rubbing his hands on a greasy apron that hung to his ankles. Rand wondered if more grime was coming off on the apron or on the man's hands. He was the first skinny innkeeper Rand had seen. "Well? Speak up, buy a drink, or get out! Do I look like a raree show?"

flʌʃɪŋ, ɹænd lɔntʃt ɪndə ðə spil i hæd pɝfɛktəɾ əɾ ɪnz bɪfɔɹ ðɪs. "aɪ pleɪ ðə flut, ən maɪ fɹɛn dʒʌɡəlz, ən jəl nɑt si tu bɛɾɝ ɪn ə jɪɹ. fəɹ ə ɡʊd ɹum ən ə ɡʊd mil, wɪl fɪl ðɪs kɑmən ɹum ə jʊɹz." hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə fɪl kɑmən ɹumz i hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi sin ðəɾ ivnɪŋ, ɪspɛʃli ðə mæn u hæd vɑməɾəd ɹaɪɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm ət ðə læst wʌn. hi hæd hæd tə stɛp laɪvli tə kip ɪz buts əntʌtʃt. hi fɔltɝd, bʌt kɑt hɪmsɛlf ən wɛn ɑn. "wil fɪl jəɹ ɪn wɪð mɛn u wɪl ɹipeɪ ðə lɪɾəl wi kɑs twɛnti taɪmz oʊvɝ wɪð ðə fuɾ ən dʒɹɪŋk ðeɪ baɪ. waɪ ʃəd - "

Flushing, Rand launched into the spiel he had perfected at inns before this. "I play the flute, and my friend juggles, and you'll not see two better in a year. For a good room and a good meal, we'll fill this common room of yours." He remembered the filled common rooms he had already seen that evening, especially the man who had vomited right in front of him at the last one. He had had to step lively to keep his boots untouched. He faltered, but caught himself and went on. "We'll fill your inn with men who will repay the little we cost twenty times over with the food and drink they buy. Why should - "

"aɪv ɡɑɾ ə mæn pleɪz ðə dʌlsɪmɝ," ði ɪnkipɝ sɛd saʊɝli.

"I've got a man plays the dulcimer," the innkeeper said sourly.

"ju hæv ə dʒɹʌŋk, sæməl heɪk," wʌn ə ðə sɝvɪŋ meɪdz sɛd. ʃi wɑz pæsɪŋ ɪm wɪð ə tʃɹeɪ ən tu mʌɡz, ən ʃi pɔz tə ɡɪv ɹænd ən mæt ə plʌmp smaɪl. "moʊs taɪmz, hi kæn si wɛl ɪnʌf tə faɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum," ʃi kənfaɪɾəd ɪn ə laʊd wɪspɝ. "hævən ivən sin ɪm ɪn tu deɪz."

"You have a drunk, Saml Hake," one of the serving maids said. She was passing him with a tray and two mugs, and she paused to give Rand and Mat a plump smile. "Most times, he can't see well enough to find the common room," she confided in a loud whisper. "Haven't even seen him in two days."

wɪθaʊt teɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz ɔf ɹænd ən mæt, heɪk kæʒəwəli bækhændəɾ əɹ əkɹɔs ðə feɪs. ʃi ɡeɪv ə sɝpɹaɪzd ɡɹʌn ən fɛl hɛvəli tə ði ənwɑʃt flɔɹ; wʌn ə ðə mʌɡz bɹoʊk, ən ðə spɪld waɪn wɑʃt ɹɪvələts ɪn ðə dɝt. "jɔɹ dɑk fəɹ ðə waɪn ən bɹeɪkɪdʒ. ɡɛt 'ɛm fɹɛʃ dʒɹɪŋks. ən hɝi. mɛn doʊn peɪ tə weɪt waɪl jə leɪz ɝaʊnd." hɪz toʊn wɑz əz ɔfhæn əz ðə bloʊ. nʌn ə ðə peɪtʃɹənz lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ðɛɹ waɪn, ən ði ʌðɝ sɝvɪŋ meɪdz kɛp ðɛɹ aɪz əvɝɾəd.

Without taking his eyes off Rand and Mat, Hake casually backhanded her across the face. She gave a surprised grunt and fell heavily to the unwashed floor; one of the mugs broke, and the spilled wine washed rivulets in the dirt. "You're docked for the wine and breakage. Get 'em fresh drinks. And hurry. Men don't pay to wait while you laze around." His tone was as offhand as the blow. None of the patrons looked up from their wine, and the other serving maids kept their eyes averted.

ðə plʌmp wʊmən ɹʌbd əɹ tʃik ən stɛɹd pjʊɹ mɝɾɝ ət heɪk, bʌt ʃi ɡæðɝd ði ɛmpti mʌɡ ən ðə bɹoʊkən pisəz ɑn əɹ tʃɹeɪ ən wɛn ɔf wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd.

The plump woman rubbed her cheek and stared pure murder at Hake, but she gathered the empty mug and the broken pieces on her tray and went off without a word.

heɪk sʌkt ɪz tiθ θɔtfəli, aɪɪŋ ɹænd ən mæt. hɪz ɡeɪz klʌŋ tə ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk sɔɹd bɪfɔɹ i pʊld ɪɾ əweɪ. "tɛl jə wʌt," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "ju kən əv ə kʌpəl ə pæləts ɪn ən ɛmpti stɔɹɹum ɪn ðə bæk. ɹumz ɑɹ tu ɪkspɛnsɪv tə ɡɪv əweɪ. jə it wən ɛvɹibɑɾiz ɡɔn. ðəɹ ɔt tə bi sʌmθɪŋ lɛft."

Hake sucked his teeth thoughtfully, eyeing Rand and Mat. His gaze clung to the heron-mark sword before he pulled it away. "Tell you what," he said finally. "You can have a couple of pallets in an empty storeroom in the back. Rooms are too expensive to give away. You eat when everybody's gone. There ought to be something left."

ɹænd wɪʃt ðəɹ wɑz ən ɪn ɪn fɔɹ kɪŋz ðeɪ hæd nɑt jɛt tʃɹaɪd. sɪns livɪŋ waɪtbɹɪdʒ i hæd mɛt kulnəs, ɪndɪfɝəns, ən aʊtʃɹaɪt hɑstɪləɾi, bʌt nʌθɪŋ ðət ɡeɪv ɪm ðə sɛns ʌv əniz ðət ðɪs mæn ən ðɪs vɪlədʒ dɪd. hi toʊl hɪmsɛlf ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ðə dɝɾ ən skwɑlɝ ən nɔɪz, bʌt ðə mɪsɡɪvɪŋz dɪd nɑt ɡoʊ əweɪ. mæt wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ heɪk əz ɪf i səspɛktəd səm tʃɹæp, bʌɾ i ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ʌv wɑntɪŋ tə ɡɪv ʌp ðə dænsɪŋ kɑɹtmən fəɹ ə bɛɾ ʌndɝ ə hɛdʒ. θʌndɝ ɹæɾəld ðə wɪndoʊz. ɹænd saɪd.

Rand wished there was an inn in Four Kings they had not yet tried. Since leaving Whitebridge he had met coolness, indifference, and outright hostility, but nothing that gave him the sense of unease that this man and this village did. He told himself it was just the dirt and squalor and noise, but the misgivings did not go away. Mat was watching Hake as if he suspected some trap, but he gave no sign of wanting to give up The Dancing Cartman for a bed under a hedge. Thunder rattled the windows. Rand sighed.

"ðə pæləts wɪl də ɪf ðəɹ klin, ən ɪf ðəɹ ɑɹ ɪnʌf klin blæŋkəts. bʌt wi it tu aʊɝz æftɝ fʊl dɑɹk, noʊ leɪɾɝ, ən ðə bɛs jə hæv. hɪɹ. wɪl ʃoʊ jə wʌt wi kən du." hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə flut keɪs, bʌt heɪk ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

"The pallets will do if they're clean, and if there are enough clean blankets. But we eat two hours after full dark, no later, and the best you have. Here. We'll show you what we can do." He reached for the flute case, but Hake shook his head.

"doʊn mæɾɝ. ðɪs lɑɾəl bi sæɾəsfaɪd wɪð ɛni kaɪndə skɹitʃɪŋ soʊ lɔŋ əz ɪt saʊnz sʌmθɪŋ laɪk mjuzɪk." hɪz aɪz tʌtʃt ɹændz sɔɹɾ əɡɛn; hɪz θɪn smaɪl tʌtʃt nʌθɪŋ bʌɾ ɪz lɪps. "it wən jə wɑnt, bʌɾ ɪf jə doʊn bɹɪŋ ðə kɹaʊɾ ɪn, aʊt jə ɡoʊ ɪn ðə stʃɹit." hi nɑɾəd oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət tu hɑɹd-feɪs mɛn sɪɾɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔl. ðeɪ wɝ nɑt dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ, ən ðɛɹ ɑɹmz wɝ θɪk ɪnʌf fəɹ lɛɡz. wən heɪk nɑɾəd ət ðɛm, ðɛɹ aɪz ʃɪftəd tə ɹænd ən mæt, flæɾ ən ɪkspɹɛʃənləs.

"Don't matter. This lot'll be satisfied with any kind of screeching so long as it sounds something like music." His eyes touched Rand's sword again; his thin smile touched nothing but his lips. "Eat when you want, but if you don't bring the crowd in, out you go in the street." He nodded over his shoulder at two hard-faced men sitting against the wall. They were not drinking, and their arms were thick enough for legs. When Hake nodded at them, their eyes shifted to Rand and Mat, flat and expressionless.

ɹænd pʊt wʌn hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt, hoʊpɪŋ ðə twɪstɪŋ ɪn ɪz stʌmək dɪd nɑt ʃoʊ ɑn ɪz feɪs. "æz lɔŋ əz wi ɡɛt wʌts əɡɹiɾ ɑn," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə lɛvəl toʊn.

Rand put one hand on his sword hilt, hoping the twisting in his stomach did not show on his face. "As long as we get what's agreed on," he said in a level tone.

heɪk blɪŋkt, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən i simd ənizi hɪmsɛlf. əbɹʌpli hi nɑɾəd. "wʌɾ aɪ sɛd, ɪzən ɪt? wɛl, ɡɛt stɑɹɾəd. jə woʊn bɹɪŋ ɛnibəɾi ɪn dʒʌst stændɪŋ ðɛɹ." hi stɔkt ɔf, skaʊlɪŋ ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ ət ðə sɝvɪŋ meɪdz əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ fɪfti kʌstəmɝz ðeɪ wɝ nɪɡlɛktɪŋ.

Hake blinked, and for a moment he seemed uneasy himself. Abruptly he nodded. "What I said, isn't it? Well, get started. You won't bring anybody in just standing there." He stalked off, scowling and shouting at the serving maids as if there were fifty customers they were neglecting.

ðəɹ wɑz ə smɔl, ɹeɪz plætfɔɹm ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə ɹum, nɪɹ ðə dɔɹ tə ðə bæk. ɹænd lɪftəɾ ə bɛntʃ ʌp ɑn ɪt, ən sɛɾəld ɪz kloʊk, blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl, ən tɑmz bʌndəl kloʊk bɪhaɪn ðə bɛntʃ wɪð ðə sɔɹd laɪɪŋ ətɑp ðɛm.

There was a small, raised platform at the far end of the room, near the door to the back. Rand lifted a bench up on it, and settled his cloak, blanketroll, and Thom's bundled cloak behind the bench with the sword lying atop them.

hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf i hæd bɪn waɪz tə kip wɛɹɪŋ ðə sɔɹɾ oʊpənli. sɔɹdz wɝ kɑmən ɪnʌf, bʌt ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk ətʃɹæktəɾ ətɛnʃən ən spɛkjəleɪʃən. nɑt fɹəm ɛvɹibɑɾi, bʌɾ ɛni noʊɾəs əɾ ɔl meɪɾ ɪm ənkʌmftəɹbəl. hi kəd bi livɪŋ ə klɪɹ tʃɹeɪl fəɹ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl - ɪf feɪdz niɾəd ðət kaɪndə tʃɹeɪl. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə. ɪn ɛni keɪs, hi wɑz ɹɪlʌktən tə stɑp wɛɹɪŋ ɪt. tæm hæd ɡɪvən ɪt tə hɪm. hɪz fɑðɝ. əz lɔŋ əz i wɔɹ ðə sɔɹd, ðəɹ wɑz stɪl səm kənɛkʃən bɪtwin tæm ən hɪm, ə θɹɛd ðət ɡeɪv ɪm ðə ɹaɪt tə stɪl kɔl tæm fɑðɝ. tu leɪt naʊ, hi θɔt. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌɾ i mɛnt, bʌɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt wɑz tʃɹu. tu leɪt.

He wondered if he had been wise to keep wearing the sword openly. Swords were common enough, but the heron-mark attracted attention and speculation. Not from everybody, but any notice at all made him uncomfortable. He could be leaving a clear trail for the Myrddraal - if Fades needed that kind of trail. They did not seem to. In any case, he was reluctant to stop wearing it. Tam had given it to him. His father. As long as he wore the sword, there was still some connection between Tam and him, a thread that gave him the right to still call Tam father. Too late now, he thought. He was not sure what he meant, but he was sure it was true. Too late.

ət ðə fɝs noʊɾ ʌv "kɑk oʊ' ðə nɔɹθ" ðə hæf-dʌzən peɪtʃɹənz ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum lɪftəd ðɛɹ hɛdz aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ waɪn. ivən ðə tu baʊnsɝz sæt fɔɹwɝɾ ə lɪɾəl. ðeɪ ɔl əplɔɾəd wən i fɪnɪʃt, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə tu tʌfs, ən wʌns mɔɹ wən mæt sɛn ə ʃaʊɝ ə kʌlɝd bɔlz spɪnɪŋ θɹu hɪz hænz. aʊtsaɪd, ðə skaɪ mʌɾɝd əɡɛn. ðə ɹeɪn wɑz hoʊldɪŋ ɔf, bʌt ðə pɹɛʃɝ ʌv ɪt wɑz pælpəbəl; ðə lɔŋɡɝ ɪt weɪɾəd, ðə hɑɹɾɝ ɪt wəd fɔl.

At the first note of "Cock o' the North" the half-dozen patrons in the common room lifted their heads out of their wine. Even the two bouncers sat forward a little. They all applauded when he finished, including the two toughs, and once more when Mat sent a shower of colored balls spinning through his hands. Outside, the sky muttered again. The rain was holding off, but the pressure of it was palpable; the longer it waited, the harder it would fall.

wɝd spɹɛd, ən baɪ ðə taɪm ɪt wɑz dɑɹk aʊtsaɪd ði ɪn wɑz pæk fʊl wɪð mɛn læfɪŋ ən tɔkɪŋ soʊ laʊd ðət ɹænd kəd bɛɹli hɪɹ wʌɾ i wɑz pleɪɪŋ. oʊnli ðə θʌndɝ oʊvɝpaʊɝd ðə nɔɪz ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum. laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz, ən ɪn ðə moʊməntɛɹi lʌlz i kəd feɪnli hɪɹ ɹeɪn dʒɹʌmɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹuf. mɛn u keɪm ɪn naʊ dʒɹɪp tʃɹeɪlz əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ.

Word spread, and by the time it was dark outside the inn was packed full with men laughing and talking so loud that Rand could barely hear what he was playing. Only the thunder overpowered the noise in the common room. Lightning flashed in the windows, and in the momentary lulls he could faintly hear rain drumming on the roof. Men who came in now dripped trails across the floor.

wɛnɛvɝ i pɔzd, vɔɪsəz ʃaʊɾəd ðə neɪmz ə tunz θɹu ðə dɪn. ə ɡʊd mɛni neɪmz i dɪd nɑt ɹɛkəɡnaɪz, ðoʊ wən i ɡɑt sʌmwʌn tə hʌm ə bɪɾ ʌv ɪt, hi ɔfən faʊn i dɪd noʊ ðə sɔŋ. ɪt hæd bɪn ðət weɪ ʌðɝ pleɪsəz, bɪfɔɹ. "dʒɑli dʒeɪm" wɑz "ɹiəz flɪŋ" hɪɹ, ən hæd bɪn "kʌlɝz ə ðə sʌn" əɾ ən ɝliɝ stɑp. səm neɪmz steɪd ðə seɪm; ʌðɝz tʃeɪnʒd wɪð tɛn maɪlz' dɪstəns, ən i hæd lɝnd nu sɔŋz, tu. "ðə dʒɹʌŋkən pɛdlɝ" wɑz ə nu wʌn, ðoʊ səmtaɪmz ɪt wɑz kɔld "tɪŋkɝ ɪn ðə kɪtʃən." "tu kɪŋz keɪm hʌntɪŋ" wɑz "tu hɔɹsəz ɹʌnɪŋ" ən sɛvɹəl ʌðɝ neɪmz bɪsaɪdz. hi pleɪd ðə wʌnz i nu, ən mɛn paʊndɪd ðə teɪbəlz fəɹ mɔɹ.

Whenever he paused, voices shouted the names of tunes through the din. A good many names he did not recognize, though when he got someone to hum a bit of it, he often found he did know the song. It had been that way other places, before. "Jolly Jaim" was "Rhea's Fling" here, and had been "Colors of the Sun" at an earlier stop. Some names stayed the same; others changed with ten miles' distance, and he had learned new songs, too. "The Drunken Peddler" was a new one, though sometimes it was called "Tinker in the Kitchen." "Two Kings Came Hunting" was "Two Horses Running" and several other names besides. He played the ones he knew, and men pounded the tables for more.

ʌðɝz kɔl fəɹ mæt tə dʒʌɡəl əɡɛn. səmtaɪmz faɪts bɹoʊk aʊt bɪtwin ðoʊz wɑntɪŋ mjuzɪk ən ðoʊz u fænsid dʒʌɡəlɪŋ. wʌns ə naɪf flæʃt, ən ə wʊmən skɹimd, ən ə mæn ɹil bæk fɹəm ə teɪbəl wɪð blʌd stʃɹimɪŋ daʊn ɪz feɪs, bʌt dʒæk ən stʃɹɑm, ðə tu baʊnsɝz, kloʊzd ɪn swɪfli ən wɪð kəmpliɾ ɪmpɑɹʃiælɪɾi θɹu ɛvɹiwʌn ɪnvɑlvd ɪndə ðə stʃɹit wɪð lʌmps ɑn ðɛɹ hɛdz. ðət wɑz ðɛɹ tæktɪk wɪð ɛni tʃɹʌbəl. ðə tɔk ən ðə læfɪŋ wɛn ɑn əz ɪf nʌθɪŋ hæɾ əkɝd. noʊbɑdi ivən lʊkt ɝaʊn ɪksɛp ðoʊz ðə baʊnsɝz dʒɑsəld ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə ðə dɔɹ.

Others called for Mat to juggle again. Sometimes fights broke out between those wanting music and those who fancied juggling. Once a knife flashed, and a woman screamed, and a man reeled back from a table with blood streaming down his face, but Jak and Strom, the two bouncers, closed in swiftly and with complete impartiality threw everyone involved into the street with lumps on their heads. That was their tactic with any trouble. The talk and the laughing went on as if nothing had occurred. Nobody even looked around except those the bouncers jostled on their way to the door.

ðə peɪtʃɹənz wɝ fɹi wɪð ðɛɹ hænz, tu, wən wʌn ə ðə sɝvɪŋ meɪdz lɛt hɝsɛlf ɡɹoʊ ənwɛɹi. mɔɹ ðən wʌns dʒæk əɹ stʃɹɑm hæd tə ɹɛskju wʌn ə ðə wɪmən, ðoʊ ðeɪ wɝ nʌn tu kwɪk əbaʊɾ ɪt. ðə weɪ heɪk kæɹiɾ ɑn, skɹimɪŋ ən ʃeɪkɪŋ ðə wʊmən ɪnvɑlvd, hi ɔlweɪz kənsɪɾɝd ɪɾ əɹ fɔlt, ən ðə tɪɹi aɪz ən stæmɝɾ əpɑlədʒiz sɛd ʃi wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə æksɛpt ɪz əpɪnjən. ðə wɪmən dʒʌmpt wɛnɛvɝ heɪk fɹaʊnd, ivən ɪf i wɑz lʊkɪŋ sʌmwɛɹ ɛls. ɹænd wʌndɝd waɪ ɛni ʌv əm pʊɾ ʌp wɪð ɪt.

The patrons were free with their hands, too, when one of the serving maids let herself grow unwary. More than once Jak or Strom had to rescue one of the women, though they were none too quick about it. The way Hake carried on, screaming and shaking the woman involved, he always considered it her fault, and the teary eyes and stammered apologies said she was willing to accept his opinion. The women jumped whenever Hake frowned, even if he was looking somewhere else. Rand wondered why any of them put up with it.

heɪk smaɪld wən i lʊkt ət ɹænd ən mæt. æftɝ ə waɪl ɹænd ɹilaɪz heɪk wɑz nɑt smaɪlɪŋ ət ðɛm; ðə smaɪlz keɪm wən ɪz aɪz slɪd bɪhaɪn ðɛm, tə wɛɹ ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk sɔɹd leɪ. wʌns, wən ɹænd sɛt ðə ɡoʊld-ænd-sɪlvɝ-tʃeɪs flut daʊn bɪsaɪɾ ɪz stul, ðə flut ɡɑɾ ə smaɪl, tu.

Hake smiled when he looked at Rand and Mat. After a while Rand realized Hake was not smiling at them; the smiles came when his eyes slid behind them, to where the heron-mark sword lay. Once, when Rand set the gold-and-silver-chased flute down beside his stool, the flute got a smile, too.

ðə nɛks taɪm i tʃeɪnʒd pleɪsəz wɪð mæt ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə deɪz, hi lin oʊvɝ tə spik ɪn mæts ɪɹ. ivən ðət kloʊs i hæd tə spik laʊdli, bʌt wɪð ɔl ðə nɔɪz i daʊɾɪd ɪf ɛniwʌn ɛls kəd hɪɹ. "heɪks gɑnə tʃɹaɪ tə ɹɑb ʌs."

The next time he changed places with Mat at the front of the dais, he leaned over to speak in Mat's ear. Even that close he had to speak loudly, but with all the noise he doubted if anyone else could hear. "Hake's going to try to rob us."

mæt nɑɾəd əz ɪf ɪt wɑz nʌθɪŋ i hæd nɑɾ ɪkspɛktəd. "wil əv tə bɑɹ əɹ dɔɹ tənaɪt."

Mat nodded as if it was nothing he had not expected. "We'll have to bar our door tonight."

"bɑɹ əɹ dɔɹ? dʒæk ən stʃɹɑm kəd bɹeɪk daʊn ə dɔɹ wɪð ðɛɹ fɪsts. lɛts ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ."

"Bar our door? Jak and Strom could break down a door with their fists. Let's get out of here."

"weɪt tɪl æftɝ wi it, ət list. aɪm hʌŋɡɹi. ðeɪ kæn də ɛniθɪŋ hɪɹ," mæt æɾəd. ðə pækt kɑmən ɹum ʃaʊɾəd ɪmpeɪʃənli fəɹ əm tə ɡɛɾ ɑn wɪð ɪt. heɪk wɑz ɡlɛɹɪŋ ət ðɛm. "ɛniweɪ, jə wɑnə slip aʊtsaɪd tənaɪt?" ən ɪspɛʃli stʃɹɔŋ kɹæk ə laɪtnɪŋ dʒɹaʊn aʊɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls, ən fəɹ ən ɪnstən ðə laɪt θɹu ðə wɪndoʊz wɑz stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ðə læmps.

"Wait till after we eat, at least. I'm hungry. They can't do anything here," Mat added. The packed common room shouted impatiently for them to get on with it. Hake was glaring at them. "Anyway, you want to sleep outside tonight?" An especially strong crack of lightning drowned out everything else, and for an instant the light through the windows was stronger than the lamps.

"aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə ɡɛɾ aʊt wɪθaʊt maɪ hɛd biɪŋ bɹoʊkən," ɹænd sɛd, bʌt mæt wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi slaʊtʃɪŋ bæk tə teɪk ɪz ɹɛst ɑn ðə stul. ɹænd saɪɾ ən lɔntʃt ɪndə "ðə ɹoʊd tə dʌn ɹɛn." ə lɑɾ ə ðɛm sim tə laɪk ðət wʌn; hi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi pleɪɾ ɪt fɔɹ taɪmz, ən ðeɪ stɪl ʃaʊɾəd fəɹ ɪt.

"I just want to get out without my head being broken," Rand said, but Mat was already slouching back to take his rest on the stool. Rand sighed and launched into "The Road to Dun Aren." A lot of them seemed to like that one; he had already played it four times, and they still shouted for it.

ðə tʃɹʌbəl wɑz ðət mæt wɑz ɹaɪt, əz fɑɹ əz i wɛnt. hi wɑz hʌŋɡɹi, tu. ən i kəd nɑt si haʊ heɪk kəd ɡɪv əm ɛni tʃɹʌbəl waɪl ðə kɑmən ɹum wɑz fʊl, ən ɡɛɾɪŋ fʊlɝ. fəɹ ɛvɹi mæn u lɛft əɹ wɑz θɹoʊn aʊt baɪ dʒæk ən stʃɹɑm, tu keɪm ɪn fɹəm ðə stʃɹit. ðeɪ ʃaʊɾəd fəɹ ðə dʒʌɡəlɪŋ əɹ fəɹ ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ tun, bʌt moʊsli ðeɪ wɝ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ən fɑndəlɪŋ ðə sɝvɪŋ meɪdz. wʌn mæn wɑz dɪfɹənt, ðoʊ.

The trouble was that Mat was right, as far as he went. He was hungry, too. And he could not see how Hake could give them any trouble while the common room was full, and getting fuller. For every man who left or was thrown out by Jak and Strom, two came in from the street. They shouted for the juggling or for a particular tune, but mostly they were interested in drinking and fondling the serving maids. One man was different, though.

hi stʊɾ aʊɾ ɪn ɛvɹi weɪ əmʌŋ ðə kɹaʊɾ ɪn ðə dænsɪŋ kɑɹtmən. mɝtʃəns əpɛɹənli hæd noʊ jus fəɹ ðə ɹʌn-daʊn ɪn; ðəɹ wɝ nɑɾ ivən ɛni pɹaɪvət daɪnɪŋ ɹumz fəɹ ðɛm, əz fɑɹ əz i kəd meɪk aʊt. ðə peɪtʃɹənz wɝ ɔl ɹʌf-dʒɹɛst, wɪð ðə tʌf skɪn ə mɛn u leɪbɝɾ ɪn ðə sʌn ən waɪnd. ðɪs mæn wɑz slikli flɛʃi, wɪð ə sɑf lʊk tə hɪz hænz, ən ə vɛlvət koʊt, ən ə dɑɹk ɡɹin vɛlvət kloʊk laɪnd wɪð blu sɪlk wɑz slʌŋ ɝaʊn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. ɔl ə hɪz kloʊðz hæɾ ən ɪkspɛnsɪv kʌt tə ðɛm. hɪz ʃuz - sɑf vɛlvət slɪpɝz, nɑt buts - wɝ nɑt meɪd fəɹ ðə ɹʌɾɪd stʃɹits ə fɔɹ kɪŋz, əɹ fəɹ ɛni stʃɹits əɾ ɔl, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ.

He stood out in every way among the crowd in The Dancing Cartman. Merchants apparently had no use for the run-down inn; there were not even any private dining rooms for them, as far as he could make out. The patrons were all rough-dressed, with the tough skin of men who labored in the sun and wind. This man was sleekly fleshy, with a soft look to his hands, and a velvet coat, and a dark green velvet cloak lined with blue silk was slung around his shoulders. All of his clothes had an expensive cut to them. His shoes - soft velvet slippers, not boots - were not made for the rutted streets of Four Kings, or for any streets at all, for that matter.

hi keɪm ɪn wɛl æftɝ dɑɹk, ʃeɪkɪŋ ðə ɹeɪn ɔf ɪz kloʊk əz i lʊkt ɝaʊnd, ə twɪst ə dɪsteɪst ɑn ɪz maʊθ. hi skæn ðə ɹum wʌns, ɔlɹɛɾi tɝnɪŋ tə ɡoʊ, ðən sʌɾənli ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ət nʌθɪŋ ɹænd kəd si ən sæt daʊn əɾ ə teɪbəl dʒæk ən stʃɹɑm hæd dʒʌst ɛmptid. ə sɝvɪŋ meɪd stɑpt əɾ ɪz teɪbəl, ðən bɹɔɾ ɪm ə mʌɡ ʌv waɪn wɪtʃ i pʊʃt tə wʌn saɪɾ ən nɛvɝ tʌtʃt əɡɛn. ʃi simd ɪn ə hɝi tə liv ɪz teɪbəl boʊθ taɪmz, ðoʊ hi dɪd nɑt tʃɹaɪ tə tʌtʃ əɹ əɹ ivən lʊk ət hɝ. wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz əbaʊɾ ɪm ðət meɪɾ əɹ ənizi, ʌðɝz u keɪm kloʊs tə hɪm noʊɾəst ɪt, tu. fəɹ ɔl ə hɪz sɑf lʊk, wɛnɛvɝ səm kæləs-hændəd wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝ dɪsaɪɾɪd tə ʃɛɹ ɪz teɪbəl, wʌn ɡlæns wɑz ɔl ɪt tʊk tə sɛn ðə mæn lʊkɪŋ ɛlswɛɹ. hi sæɾ əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ noʊ wʌn ɛls ɪn ðə ɹum bʌɾ ɪm - ən ɹænd ən mæt. ðɛm i wɑtʃt oʊvɝ stipəl hænz ðət ɡlɪɾɝd wɪð ə ɹɪŋ ɑn itʃ fɪŋɡɝ. hi wɑtʃt əm wɪð ə smaɪl ə sæɾəsfaɪd ɹɛkəɡnɪʃən.

He came in well after dark, shaking the rain off his cloak as he looked around, a twist of distaste on his mouth. He scanned the room once, already turning to go, then suddenly gave a start at nothing Rand could see and sat down at a table Jak and Strom had just emptied. A serving maid stopped at his table, then brought him a mug of wine which he pushed to one side and never touched again. She seemed in a hurry to leave his table both times, though he did not try to touch her or even look at her. Whatever it was about him that made her uneasy, others who came close to him noticed it, too. For all of his soft look, whenever some callus-handed wagon driver decided to share his table, one glance was all it took to send the man looking elsewhere. He sat as if there were no one else in the room but him - and Rand and Mat. Them he watched over steepled hands that glittered with a ring on each finger. He watched them with a smile of satisfied recognition.

ɹænd mɝmɝd tə mæt əz ðeɪ wɝ tʃeɪnʒɪŋ pleɪsəz əɡɛn, ən mæt nɑɾəd. "aɪ sɔ hɪm," hi mʌɾɝd. "hu ɪz hi? aɪ kip θɪŋkɪŋ aɪ noʊ hɪm."

Rand murmured to Mat as they were changing places again, and Mat nodded. "I saw him," he muttered. "Who is he? I keep thinking I know him."

ðə seɪm θɔt hæɾ əkɝd tə ɹænd, tɪklɪŋ ðə bæk ə hɪz mɛmɹi, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt bɹɪŋ ɪt fɔɹwɝd. jɛɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ ðət feɪs wɑz wʌn i hæd nɛvɝ sin bɪfɔɹ.

The same thought had occurred to Rand, tickling the back of his memory, but he could not bring it forward. Yet he was sure that face was one he had never seen before.

wən ðeɪ hæd bɪn pɝfɔɹmɪŋ fəɹ tu aʊɝz, əz nɪɹ əz ɹænd kəɾ ɛstəmeɪt, hi slɪp ðə fluɾ ɪndə ɪts keɪs ən i ən mæt ɡæðɝɾ ʌp ðɛɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz. əz ðeɪ wɝ stɛpɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ðə loʊ plætfɔɹm, heɪk keɪm bʌsəlɪŋ ʌp, æŋɡɝ twɪstɪŋ ɪz nɛɹoʊ feɪs.

When they had been performing for two hours, as near as Rand could estimate, he slipped the flute into its case and he and Mat gathered up their belongings. As they were stepping down from the low platform, Hake came bustling up, anger twisting his narrow face.

"ɪts taɪm tə it," ɹænd sɛd tə fɔɹstɔl hɪm, "ænd wi doʊnt wɑn əɹ θɪŋz stoʊlən. jə wɑnə tɛl ðə kʊk?" heɪk hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, stɪl æŋɡɹi, tʃɹaɪɪŋ ʌnsəksɛsfəli tə kip ɪz aɪz ɔf wʌt ɹænd hɛld ɪn ɪz ɑɹmz. kæʒəwəli ɹænd ʃɪftəɾ ɪz bʌndəlz soʊ hi kəd ɹɛst wʌn hæn ɑn ðə sɔɹd. "ɔɹ jə kən tʃɹaɪ θɹoʊɪŋ əs aʊt." hi meɪd ði ɛmfəsəs dɪlɪbɝətli, ðən æɾəd, "ðɛɹz ə lɑɾ ə naɪt lɛft fəɹ əs tə pleɪ, jɛt. wɪv tə kip əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ ʌp ɪf wɝ gɑnə pɝfɔɹm wɛl ɪnʌf tə kip ðɪs kɹaʊd spɛndɪŋ mʌni. haʊ lɔŋ dʒju θɪŋk ðɪs ɹum wɪl steɪ fʊl ɪf wi fɔl oʊvɝ fɹəm hʌŋɡɝ?"

"It's time to eat," Rand said to forestall him, "and we don't want our things stolen. You want to tell the cook?" Hake hesitated, still angry, trying unsuccessfully to keep his eyes off what Rand held in his arms. Casually Rand shifted his bundles so he could rest one hand on the sword. "Or you can try throwing us out." He made the emphasis deliberately, then added, "There's a lot of night left for us to play, yet. We have to keep our strength up if we're going to perform well enough to keep this crowd spending money. How long do you think this room will stay full if we fall over from hunger?"

heɪks aɪz twɪtʃt oʊvɝ ðə ɹum fʊl ə mɛn pʊɾɪŋ mʌni ɪn ɪz pɑkət, ðən i tɝn ən stʌk ɪz hɛd θɹu ðə dɔɹ tə ðə ɹɪɹ ə ði ɪn. "fid 'ɛm!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. ɹaʊndɪŋ ɑn ɹænd ən mæt, hi snɑɹəld, "doʊn bi ɔl naɪɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt. aɪ ɪkspɛk jə ʌp ðəɹ tɪl ðə læs mænz ɡɔn."

Hake's eyes twitched over the room full of men putting money in his pocket, then he turned and stuck his head through the door to the rear of the inn. "Feed 'em!" he shouted. Rounding on Rand and Mat, he snarled, "Don't be all night about it. I expect you up there till the last man's gone."

səm ə ðə peɪtʃɹənz wɝ ʃaʊɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə mjuzɪʃən ən ðə dʒʌɡəlɝ, ən heɪk tɝn tə suð ðɛm. ðə mæn ɪn ðə vɛlvət kloʊk wɑz wʌn ə ði æŋkʃəs wʌnz. ɹænd moʊʃən mæt tə fɑloʊ hɪm.

Some of the patrons were shouting for the musician and the juggler, and Hake turned to soothe them. The man in the velvet cloak was one of the anxious ones. Rand motioned Mat to follow him.

ə staʊt dɔɹ sɛpɝeɪɾəd ðə kɪtʃən fɹəm ðə fɹʌn ə ði ɪn, ænd, ɪksɛpt wən ɪɾ oʊpən tə lɛɾ ə sɝvɪŋ meɪd θɹu, ðə ɹeɪn paʊndɪŋ ðə ɹuf wɑz laʊɾɝ ɪn ðə kɪtʃən ðən ðə ʃaʊts fɹəm ðə kɑmən ɹum. ɪt wɑz ə bɪɡ ɹum, hɑɾ ən stimi fɹəm stoʊvz ən ʌvənz, wɪð ə hjudʒ teɪbəl kʌvɝd wɪð hæf-pɹipɛɹd fuɾ ən dɪʃəz ɹɛɾi tə bi sɝvd. səm ə ðə sɝvɪŋ meɪdz sæt klʌstɝɾ ɑn ə bɛntʃ nɪɹ ðə ɹɪɹ dɔɹ, ɹʌbɪŋ ðɛɹ fiɾ ən tʃæɾɝɪŋ əweɪ ɔl ət wʌns wɪð ðə fæt kʊk, hu tɔk bæk ət ðə seɪm taɪm ən weɪvd ə bɪɡ spun tə ɛmfəsaɪz əɹ pɔɪns. ðeɪ ɔl ɡlænst ʌp əz ɹænd ən mæt keɪm ɪn, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt sloʊ ðɛɹ kɑnvɝseɪʃən əɹ stɑp ðɛɹ fʊt ɹʌbɪŋ.

A stout door separated the kitchen from the front of the inn, and, except when it opened to let a serving maid through, the rain pounding the roof was louder in the kitchen than the shouts from the common room. It was a big room, hot and steamy from stoves and ovens, with a huge table covered with half-prepared food and dishes ready to be served. Some of the serving maids sat clustered on a bench near the rear door, rubbing their feet and chattering away all at once with the fat cook, who talked back at the same time and waved a big spoon to emphasize her points. They all glanced up as Rand and Mat came in, but it did not slow their conversation or stop their foot rubbing.

"wi ɔt tə ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ə hɪɹ waɪl wɪv ðə tʃæns," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli, bʌt mæt ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, hɪz aɪz fɪkst oʊ ðə tu pleɪts ðə kʊk wɑz fɪlɪŋ wɪð bif ən pəteɪɾoʊz ən piz. ʃi hɑɹdli lʊkt ət ðə tu ʌv ðɛm, kipɪŋ ʌp əɹ tɔk wɪð ði ʌðɝ wɪmən waɪl ʃi pʊʃt θɪŋz əsaɪɾ ɑn ðə teɪbəl wɪð əɹ ɛlboʊz ən sɛt ðə pleɪts daʊn, æɾɪŋ fɔɹks.

"We ought to get out of here while we have the chance," Rand said softly, but Mat shook his head, his eyes fixed oh the two plates the cook was filling with beef and potatoes and peas. She hardly looked at the two of them, keeping up her talk with the other women while she pushed things aside on the table with her elbows and set the plates down, adding forks.

"æftɝ wi iɾ ɪz taɪm ɪnʌf." mæt slɪɾ ɑntu ə bɛntʃ ən bɪɡæn juzɪŋ ɪz fɔɹk əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ə ʃʌvəl.

"After we eat is time enough." Mat slid onto a bench and began using his fork as if it were a shovel.

ɹænd saɪd, bʌɾ i wɑz ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn mæt. hi hæd hæɾ oʊnli ə bʌt-ɛn ə bɹɛd tə it sɪns ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ. hɪz bɛli fɛlt əz ɛmpti əz ə bɛɡɝz pɝs, ən ðə kʊkɪŋ smɛlz ðət fɪl ðə kɪtʃən dɪd nɑt hɛlp. hi kwɪkli hæɾ ɪz maʊθ fʊl, ðoʊ mæt wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪz pleɪt ɹifɪl baɪ ðə kʊk bɪfɔɹ i hæd fɪnɪʃt hæf ə hɪz.

Rand sighed, but he was right behind Mat. He had had only a butt-end of bread to eat since the night before. His belly felt as empty as a beggar's purse, and the cooking smells that filled the kitchen did not help. He quickly had his mouth full, though Mat was getting his plate refilled by the cook before he had finished half of his.

hi dɪd nɑt min tə ivzdʒɹɑp ɑn ðə wɪmənz tɔk, bʌt səm ə ðə wɝdz ɹitʃt aʊɾ ən ɡɹæb hɪm.

He did not mean to eavesdrop on the women's talk, but some of the words reached out and grabbed him.

"saʊnz kɹeɪzi tə mi."

"Sounds crazy to me."

"kɹeɪzi əɹ nɑt, ɪts wʌɾ aɪ hɪɹ. hi wɛn tə hæf ði ɪnz ɪn taʊn bɪfɔɹ i keɪm hɪɹ. dʒʌst wɔkt ɪn, lʊkt ɝaʊnd, ən wɔkt aʊt wɪθaʊt seɪɪŋ wʌn wɝd, ivən ət ðə ɹɔɪəl ɪn. laɪk ɪt wɑzn ɹeɪnɪŋ əɾ ɔl."

"Crazy or not, it's what I hear. He went to half the inns in town before he came here. Just walked in, looked around, and walked out without saying one word, even at the Royal Inn. Like it wasn't raining at all."

"meɪbi hi θɔt hɪɹ wɑz ðə moʊs kʌmftəɹbəl." ðət bɹɔt ɡeɪlz ə læftɝ.

"Maybe he thought here was the most comfortable." That brought gales of laughter.

"wʌɾ aɪ hɪɹ ɪz i dɪdn ivən ɡɛt tə fɔɹ kɪŋz tɪl æftɝ naɪtfɔl, ən ɪz hɔɹsəz bloʊɪŋ laɪk ðeɪd bɪn pʊʃt hɑɹd."

"What I hear is he didn't even get to Four Kings till after nightfall, and his horses blowing like they'd been pushed hard."

"wɛɹəɾ i kʌm fɹʌm, tə ɡɛt kɑɾ aʊɾ æftɝ dɑɹk? noʊbɑdi bʌɾ ə ful əɹ ə mædmæn tʃɹævəlz ɛniwɛɹ ən plænz ɪt ðət bædli."

"Where'd he come from, to get caught out after dark? Nobody but a fool or a madman travels anywhere and plans it that badly."

"wɛl, meɪbi hiz ə ful, bʌt hiz ə ɹɪtʃ wʌn. aɪ hɪɹ i ivən əz ənʌðɝ kæɹɪdʒ fəɹ ɪz sɝvəns ən bæɡədʒ. ðɛɹz mʌni ðɛɹ, mɑɹk maɪ wɝdz. dɪd jə si ðət kloʊk ə hɪz? aɪ wʊdn maɪn hævɪŋ ðət maɪ aʊnsɛlf."

"Well, maybe he's a fool, but he's a rich one. I hear he even has another carriage for his servants and baggage. There's money there, mark my words. Did you see that cloak of his? I wouldn't mind having that my ownself."

"hiz ə lɪɾəl plʌmp fəɹ maɪ teɪst, bʌɾ aɪ ɔlweɪz seɪ ə mæn kæn bi tu fæɾ ɪf ɪnʌf ɡoʊl kʌmz wɪð ɪt." ðeɪ ɔl dʌbəld oʊvɝ ɡɪɡəlɪŋ, ən ðə kʊk θɹu bæk əɹ hɛɾ ən ɹɔɹd wɪð læftɝ.

"He's a little plump for my taste, but I always say a man can't be too fat if enough gold comes with it." They all doubled over giggling, and the cook threw back her head and roared with laughter.

ɹænd dʒɹɑpt ɪz fɔɹk ɑn ɪz pleɪt. ə θɔɾ i dɪd nɑt laɪk bʌbəld ɪn ɪz hɛd. "aɪl bi bæk ɪn ə mɪnət," hi sɛd. mæt bɛɹli nɑɾəd, stʌfɪŋ ə pis ə pəteɪtoʊ ɪndə hɪz maʊθ.

Rand dropped his fork on his plate. A thought he did not like bubbled in his head. "I'll be back in a minute," he said. Mat barely nodded, stuffing a piece of potato into his mouth.

ɹænd pɪkt ʌp ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt əlɔŋ wɪð ɪz kloʊk əz i stʊd, ən bʌkəld ɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz weɪst ɑn ðə weɪ tə ðə bæk dɔɹ. noʊ wʌn peɪɾ ɪm ɛni maɪnd.

Rand picked up his sword belt along with his cloak as he stood, and buckled it around his waist on the way to the back door. No one paid him any mind.

ðə ɹeɪn wɑz bʌkəɾɪŋ daʊn. hi swʌŋ ɪz kloʊk ɝaʊn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən pʊl ðə hʊɾ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd, hoʊldɪŋ ðə kloʊk kloʊzd əz i tʃɹɑɾəd əkɹɔs ðə steɪbliɑɹd. ə kɝɾən ʌv wɔɾɝ hɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪksɛpt wən laɪtnɪŋ flæʃt, bʌɾ i faʊnd wʌɾ i wɑz hʌntɪŋ. ðə hɔɹsəz hæd bɪn teɪkən ɪndə ðə steɪbəl, bʌt ðə tu blæk-lækɝd kæɹɪdʒɪz ɡlɪsənd wɛtli aʊtsaɪd. θʌndɝ ɡɹʌmbəld, ən ə boʊlt ə laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹikt əbʌv ði ɪn. ɪn ðə bɹif bɝst ə laɪɾ i meɪɾ aʊɾ ə neɪm ɪn ɡoʊl skɹɪpt ɑn ðə koʊtʃ dɔɹz. haʊəl ɡoʊd.

The rain was bucketing down. He swung his cloak around his shoulders and pulled the hood over his head, holding the cloak closed as he trotted across the stableyard. A curtain of water hid everything except when lightning flashed, but he found what he was hunting. The horses had been taken into the stable, but the two black-lacquered carriages glistened wetly outside. Thunder grumbled, and a bolt of lightning streaked above the inn. In the brief burst of light he made out a name in gold script on the coach doors. Howal Gode.

ʌnmaɪnfəl ə ðə ɹeɪn biɾɪŋ ət hɪm, hi stʊd stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə neɪm i kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ si. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd wɛɹ i hæd læst sin blæk-lækɝd koʊtʃɪz wɪð ðɛɹ oʊnɝz' neɪmz ɑn ðə dɔɹ, ən slik, oʊvɝfɛd mɛn ɪn sɪlk-laɪn vɛlvət kloʊks ən vɛlvət slɪpɝz. waɪtbɹɪdʒ. eɪ waɪtbɹɪdʒ mɝtʃən kəɾ əv ə pɝfəkli lədʒɪɾəmət ɹizən tə bi ɑn ɪz weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn. ə ɹizən ðət sɛnz ɪm tə hæf ði ɪnz ɪn taʊn bɪfɔɹ i tʃuzəz ðə wʌn wɛɹ jə ɑɹ? ə ɹizən ðət meɪks ɪm lʊk ət jə əz ɪf hiz faʊnd wʌt hiz sɝtʃɪŋ fɔɹ?

Unmindful of the rain beating at him, he stood staring at the name he could no longer see. He remembered where he had last seen black-lacquered coaches with their owners' names on the door, and sleek, overfed men in silk-lined velvet cloaks and velvet slippers. Whitebridge. A Whitebridge merchant could have a perfectly legitimate reason to be on his way to Caemlyn. A reason that sends him to half the inns in town before he chooses the one where you are? A reason that makes him look at you as if he's found what he's searching for?

ɹænd ʃɪvɝd, ən sʌɾənli hi wɑz əwɛɹ ə ɹeɪn tʃɹɪklɪŋ daʊn ɪz bæk. hɪz kloʊk wɑz taɪtli woʊvən, bʌɾ ɪt hæd nɛvɝ bɪn mɛn tə stæn ʌp tə ðɪs kaɪndə daʊnpɔɹ. hi hɝid bæk tə ði ɪn, splæʃɪŋ θɹu dipənɪŋ pʌɾəlz. dʒæk blɑk ðə dɔɹ əz i stɑɹɾəd θɹu.

Rand shivered, and suddenly he was aware of rain trickling down his back. His cloak was tightly woven, but it had never been meant to stand up to this kind of downpour. He hurried back to the inn, splashing through deepening puddles. Jak blocked the door as he started through.

"wɛl, wɛl, wɛl. aʊt hɪɹ əloʊn ɪn ðə dɑɹk. dɑɹks deɪnʒɝəs, bɔɪ."

"Well, well, well. Out here alone in the dark. Dark's dangerous, boy."

ɹeɪn slɪkt ɹændz hɛɹ daʊn əkɹɔs ɪz fɔɹhɛd. ðə steɪbliɑɹd wɑz ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ðɛm. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf heɪk hæd dɪsaɪɾɪd i wɑntəd ðə sɔɹɾ ən ðə flut bædli ɪnʌf tə fɔɹɡoʊ kipɪŋ ðə kɹaʊɾ ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum.

Rain slicked Rand's hair down across his forehead. The stableyard was empty except for them. He wondered if Hake had decided he wanted the sword and the flute badly enough to forgo keeping the crowd in the common room.

bɹʌʃɪŋ wɔɾɝ aʊɾ ə hɪz aɪz wɪð wʌn hænd, hi pʊt ði ʌðɝ ɑn ɪz sɔɹd. ivən wɛt, ðə nɑbi lɛðɝ meɪɾ ə ʃʊɹ ɡɹɪp fəɹ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. "hæz heɪk dɪsaɪɾɪd ɔl ðoʊz mɛn wɪl steɪ dʒʌs fəɹ ɪz eɪl, ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ wɛɹ ðɛɹz ɛntɝteɪnmənt, tu? ɪf i hæz, wɪl kɔl ðə mil ivən fəɹ wʌt wiv dʌn soʊ fɑɹ ən bi ɑn əɹ weɪ."

Brushing water out of his eyes with one hand, he put the other on his sword. Even wet, the nobby leather made a sure grip for his fingers. "Has Hake decided all those men will stay just for his ale, instead of going where there's entertainment, too? If he has, we'll call the meal even for what we've done so far and be on our way."

dʒɹaɪ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, ðə bɪɡ mæn lʊkt aʊɾ ət ðə ɹeɪn ən snɔɹɾɪd. "ɪn ðɪs?" hɪz aɪz slɪd daʊn tə ɹændz hæn ɑn ðə sɔɹd. "ju noʊ, mi ən stʃɹɑm ɡɑɾ ə bɛt. hi fɪɡjɝz jə stoʊl ðət fɹəm jəɹ oʊld ɡɹændmʌðɝ. mi, aɪ fɪɡjɝ jəɹ ɡɹændmʌðɝd kɪk jə ɹaʊn ðə pɪɡpən ən hæŋ jə aʊt tə dʒɹaɪ." hi ɡɹɪnd. hɪz tiθ wɝ kɹʊkəɾ ən jɛloʊ, ən ðə ɡɹɪn meɪɾ ɪm lʊk ivən minɝ. "naɪts lɔŋ jɛt, bɔɪ."

Dry in the doorway, the big man looked out at the rain and snorted. "In this?" His eyes slid down to Rand's hand on the sword. "You know, me and Strom got a bet. He figures you stole that from your old grandmother. Me, I figure your grandmother'd kick you round the pigpen and hang you out to dry." He grinned. His teeth were crooked and yellow, and the grin made him look even meaner. "Night's long yet, boy."

ɹænd bɹʌʃt pæs hɪm, ən dʒæk lɛɾ ɪm baɪ wɪð ən ʌɡli tʃʌkəl.

Rand brushed past him, and Jak let him by with an ugly chuckle.

ɪnsaɪd, hi tɔst ɔf ɪz kloʊk ən dʒɹɑpt ɑn ðə bɛntʃ ət ðə teɪbəl i hæd lɛft oʊnli mɪnəts bɪfɔɹ. mæt wɑz dʌn wɪð ɪz sɛkən pleɪɾ ən wɝkɪŋ ɑn ə θɝd, iɾɪŋ mɔɹ sloʊli naʊ, bʌɾ ɪntɛnli, əz ɪf i plæn tə fɪnɪʃ ɛvɹi baɪɾ ɪf ɪt kɪl hɪm. dʒæk tʊk ʌp ə pleɪs baɪ ðə dɔɹ tə ðə steɪbliɑɹd, linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔl ən wɑtʃɪŋ ðɛm. ivən ðə kʊk sim tə fil noʊ ɝdʒ tə tɔk wɪð ɪm ðɛɹ.

Inside, he tossed off his cloak and dropped on the bench at the table he had left only minutes before. Mat was done with his second plate and working on a third, eating more slowly now, but intently, as if he planned to finish every bite if it killed him. Jak took up a place by the door to the stableyard, leaning against the wall and watching them. Even the cook seemed to feel no urge to talk with him there.

"hiz fɹəm waɪtbɹɪdʒ," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ nid tə seɪ hu "hi" wɑz. mæts hɛd swɪvəl təwɔɹd hɪm, ə pis ə bif ɑn ði ɛn ə ðə fɔɹk səspɛndəd hæfweɪ tə hɪz maʊθ. kɑnʃəs ə dʒæk wɑtʃɪŋ, ɹænd stɝd ðə fuɾ ɑn ɪz pleɪt. hi kəd nɑɾ əv ɡɑɾən ə maʊθfʊl daʊn ɪf i hæd bɪn stɑɹvɪŋ, bʌɾ i tʃɹaɪd tə pɹitɛn ən ɪntʃɹəst ɪn ðə piz əz i toʊl mæt əbaʊt ðə kæɹɪdʒɪz, ən wʌt ðə wɪmən hæd sɛd, ɪn keɪs mæt hæd nɑt bɪn lɪsnɪŋ.

"He's from Whitebridge," Rand said softly. There was no need to say who "he" was. Mat's head swiveled toward him, a piece of beef on the end of the fork suspended halfway to his mouth. Conscious of Jak watching, Rand stirred the food on his plate. He could not have gotten a mouthful down if he had been starving, but he tried to pretend an interest in the peas as he told Mat about the carriages, and what the women had said, in case Mat had not been listening.

ɑbviəsli hi hæd nɑt bɪn. mæt blɪŋkt ɪn sɝpɹaɪz ən wɪsəl bɪtwin ɪz tiθ, ðən fɹaʊn ət ðə miɾ ɑn ɪz fɔɹk ən ɡɹʌntɪɾ əz i tɔs ðə fɔɹk ɑntu hɪz pleɪt. ɹænd wɪʃt i wəd meɪk ət list ən ɛfɝt tə bi sɝkəmspɛkt.

Obviously he had not been. Mat blinked in surprise and whistled between his teeth, then frowned at the meat on his fork and grunted as he tossed the fork onto his plate. Rand wished he would make at least an effort to be circumspect.

"æftɝ ʌs," mæt sɛd wən i fɪnɪʃt. ðə kɹisɪz ɪn mæts fɔɹhɛd dipənd. "eɪ dɑɹkfɹɛnd?"

"After us," Mat said when he finished. The creases in Mat's forehead deepened. "A Darkfriend?"

"meɪbi. aɪ doʊnt noʊ." ɹænd ɡlænst ət dʒæk ən ðə bɪɡ mæn stʃɹɛtʃt ɪlæbɹətli, ʃɹʌɡɪŋ ʃoʊldɝz əz bɪɡ əz ɛni blæksmɪθs. "du jə θɪŋk wi kən ɡɛt pæs hɪm?"

"Maybe. I don't know." Rand glanced at Jak and the big man stretched elaborately, shrugging shoulders as big as any blacksmith's. "Do you think we can get past him?"

"nɑt wɪθaʊɾ ɪm meɪkɪŋ ɪnʌf nɔɪz tə bɹɪŋ heɪk ən ði ʌðɝ wʌn. aɪ nu wi ʃəd nɛvɝ əv stɑp hɪɹ."

"Not without him making enough noise to bring Hake and the other one. I knew we should never have stopped here."

ɹænd ɡeɪpt, bʌt bɪfɔɹ i kəd seɪ ɛniθɪŋ heɪk pʊʃt θɹu ðə dɔɹ fɹəm ðə kɑmən ɹum. stʃɹɑm bʌlk lɑɹdʒ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. dʒæk stɛpt ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə bæk dɔɹ. "ju gɑnə iɾ ɔl naɪt?" heɪk bɑɹkt. "aɪ dɪdn fid jə soʊ jə kəd laɪ ɝaʊn aʊt hɪɹ."

Rand gaped, but before he could say anything Hake pushed through the door from the common room. Strom bulked large over his shoulder. Jak stepped in front of the back door. "You going to eat all night?" Hake barked. "I didn't feed you so you could lie around out here."

ɹænd lʊkt əɾ ɪz fɹɛnd. leɪɾɝ, mæt maʊðd, ən ðeɪ ɡæðɝd ðɛɹ θɪŋz ʌndɝ ðə wɑtʃfəl aɪz ə heɪk, stʃɹɑm, ən dʒæk.

Rand looked at his friend. Later, Mat mouthed, and they gathered their things under the watchful eyes of Hake, Strom, and Jak.

ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum, kɹaɪz fəɹ dʒʌɡəlɪŋ ən ðə neɪmz ə tunz bɝs θɹu ðə klæmɝ əz sun əz ɹænd ən mæt əpɪɹd. ðə mæn ɪn ðə vɛlvət kloʊk - haʊəl ɡoʊd - stɪl əpɪɹd tə ɪɡnɔɹ ɛvɹiwʌn ɝaʊn hɪm, bʌɾ i wɑz nʌnðəlɛs siɾəd ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz tʃɛɹ. ət ðə saɪɾ ə ðɛm i lin bæk, ðə sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl ɹɪtɝnɪŋ tə hɪz lɪps.

In the common room, cries for juggling and the names of tunes burst through the clamor as soon as Rand and Mat appeared. The man in the velvet cloak - Howal Gode - still appeared to ignore everyone around him, but he was nonetheless seated on the edge of his chair. At the sight of them he leaned back, the satisfied smile returning to his lips.

ɹænd tʊk ðə fɝs tɝn ət ðə fɹʌn ə ðə deɪz, pleɪɪŋ "dʒɹɔɪŋ wɔɾɝ fɹəm ðə wɛl" wɪð oʊnli hæf ɪz maɪn ɑn ɪt. noʊ wʌn sim tə noʊɾəs ðə fju ɹɔŋ noʊts. hi tʃɹaɪd tə θɪŋk ə haʊ ðeɪ wɝ gɑnə ɡɛɾ əweɪ, ən tʃɹaɪd tə əvɔɪd lʊkɪŋ ət ɡoʊd, tu. ɪf i wɑz æftɝ ðɛm, ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɔɪn ɪn lɛɾɪŋ ɪm noʊ ðeɪ nu ɪt. əz fəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ əweɪ. . . .

Rand took the first turn at the front of the dais, playing "Drawing Water From the Well" with only half his mind on it. No one seemed to notice the few wrong notes. He tried to think of how they were going to get away, and tried to avoid looking at Gode, too. If he was after them, there was no point in letting him know they knew it. As for getting away. . . .

hi hæd nɛvɝ ɹilaɪz bɪfɔɹ wʌɾ ə ɡʊd tʃɹæp ən ɪn meɪd. heɪk, dʒæk, ən stʃɹɑm dɪd nɑɾ ivən əv tə kip ə kloʊs aɪ ɑn ðɛm; ðə kɹaʊd wəd lɛɾ əm noʊ ɪf i əɹ mæt lɛf ðə deɪz. əz lɔŋ əz ðə kɑmən ɹum wɑz fʊl ə pipəl, heɪk kəd nɑt sɛn dʒæk ən stʃɹɑm æftɝ ðɛm, bʌɾ əz lɔŋ əz ðə kɑmən ɹum wɑz fʊl ə pipəl ðeɪ kəd nɑt ɡɛɾ əweɪ wɪθaʊt heɪk noʊɪŋ. ən ɡoʊd wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ðɛɹ ɛvɹi muv, tu. ɪt wɑz soʊ fʌni hi wʊɾə læft ɪf i hæd nɑt bɪn ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə θɹoʊɪŋ ʌp. ðeɪ wəd dʒʌst əv tə bi wɛɹi ən weɪt ðɛɹ tʃæns.

He had never realized before what a good trap an inn made. Hake, Jak, and Strom did not even have to keep a close eye on them; the crowd would let them know if he or Mat left the dais. As long as the common room was full of people, Hake could not send Jak and Strom after them, but as long as the common room was full of people they could not get away without Hake knowing. And Gode was watching their every move, too. It was so funny he would have laughed if he had not been on the point of throwing up. They would just have to be wary and wait their chance.

wən i tʃeɪnʒd pleɪsəz wɪð mæt, ɹænd ɡɹoʊn tə hɪmsɛlf. mæt ɡlɛɹɾ ət heɪk, ət stʃɹɑm, ət dʒæk, wɪθaʊɾ ə kɛɹ tə wɛðɝ ðeɪ noʊɾəst əɹ wʌndɝd waɪ. wən i wɑz nɑɾ æktʃəli  hænlɪŋ ðə bɔlz, hɪz hæn ɹɛstəɾ ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt. ɹænd hɪst ət hɪm, bʌɾ i peɪd noʊ ətɛnʃən. ɪf heɪk sɔ ðət ɹubi, hi maɪt nɑt weɪɾ əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn. ɪf ðə mɛn ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum sɔ ɪt, hæf ə ðɛm maɪt dʒɔɪn ɪn wɪð heɪk.

When he changed places with Mat, Rand groaned to himself. Mat glared at Hake, at Strom, at Jak, without a care to whether they noticed or wondered why. When he was not actually handling the balls, his hand rested under his coat. Rand hissed at him, but he paid no attention. If Hake saw that ruby, he might not wait until they were alone. If the men in the common room saw it, half of them might join in with Hake.

wɝst ʌv ɔl, mæt stɛɹɾ ət ðə waɪtbɹɪdʒ mɝtʃənt - ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnd? - twaɪs əz hɑɹɾ əz əɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls, ən ɡoʊd noʊɾəst. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ hi kəɾ əvɔɪd noʊɾɪsɪŋ. bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt dɪstɝb ɪz əplɑm ɪn ðə list. hɪz smaɪl dipənd, ɪf ɛniθɪŋ, ən i nɑɾəd tə mæt əz ɪf tə ən oʊld əkweɪntəns, ðən lʊkt ət ɹænd ən ɹeɪzd ə kwɛstʃənɪŋ aɪbɹaʊ. ɹænd dɪd nɑt wɑnə noʊ wʌt ðə kwɛstʃən wɑz. hi tʃɹaɪd tə əvɔɪd lʊkɪŋ ət ðə mæn, bʌɾ i nu ɪt wɑz tu leɪt fəɹ ðæt. tu leɪt. tu leɪɾ əɡɛn.

Worst of all, Mat stared at the Whitebridge merchant - the Darkfriend? - twice as hard as at anyone else, and Gode noticed. There was no way he could avoid noticing. But it did not disturb his aplomb in the least. His smile deepened, if anything, and he nodded to Mat as if to an old acquaintance, then looked at Rand and raised a questioning eyebrow. Rand did not want to know what the question was. He tried to avoid looking at the man, but he knew it was too late for that. Too late. Too late again.

oʊnli wʌn θɪŋ sim tə ʃeɪk ðə vɛlvət-kloʊk mænz ikwəlɪbɹiəm. ɹændz sɔɹd. hi hæd lɛft ɪɾ ɑn. tu əɹ θɹi mɛn stæɡɝɾ ʌp tə æsk ɪf i θɔɾ ɪz pleɪɪŋ wɑz soʊ bæd ðəɾ i niɾəd pɹətɛkʃən, bʌt nʌn ə ðɛm hæd noʊɾəst ðə hɛɹən ɑn ðə hɪlt. ɡoʊd noʊɾəst. hɪz peɪl hænz klɛntʃt, ən i fɹaʊn ət ðə sɔɹd fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm bɪfɔɹ ɪz smaɪl keɪm bæk. wən ɪt dɪd, ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz ʃʊɹ əz bɪfɔɹ.

Only one thing seemed to shake the velvet-cloaked man's equilibrium. Rand's sword. He had left it on. Two or three men staggered up to ask if he thought his playing was so bad that he needed protection, but none of them had noticed the heron on the hilt. Gode noticed. His pale hands clenched, and he frowned at the sword for a long time before his smile came back. When it did, it was not as sure as before.

wʌn ɡʊd θɪŋ, ət list, ɹænd θɔt. ɪf i bɪlivz aɪ kən lɪv ʌp tə ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk, meɪbi hɪl liv əs əloʊn. ðən ɔl wɪv tə wɝi əbaʊɾ ɪz heɪk ən ɪz bʊliz. ɪt wɑz hɑɹdli ə kʌmfɝɾɪŋ θɔt, ænd, sɔɹɾ əɹ noʊ sɔɹd, ɡoʊd kɛpt wɑtʃɪŋ. ən smaɪlɪŋ.

One good thing, at least, Rand thought. If he believes I can live up to the heron-mark, maybe he'll leave us alone. Then all we have to worry about is Hake and his bullies. It was hardly a comforting thought, and, sword or no sword, Gode kept watching. And smiling.

tə ɹænd ðə naɪt sim tə læst ə jɪɹ. ɔl ðoʊz aɪz lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm: heɪk ən dʒæk ən stʃɹɑm laɪk vʌltʃɝz wɑtʃɪŋ ə ʃip kɑɾ ɪn ə bɑɡ, ɡoʊd weɪɾɪŋ laɪk sʌmθɪŋ ivən wɝs. hi bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk ðəɾ ɛvɹibɑɾi ɪn ðə ɹum wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ wɪð səm hɪɾən moʊɾɪv. saʊɝ waɪn fjumz ən ðə stɛntʃ ə dɝɾi, swɛɾɪŋ bɑɾiz meɪɾ ɪz hɛd swɪm, ən ðə dɪn ə vɔɪsəz biɾ əɾ ɪm tɪl ɪz aɪz blɝɾ ən ivən ðə saʊn ə hɪz oʊn flut skɹætʃt əɾ ɪz ɪɹz. ðə kɹæʃ ə ðə θʌndɝ sim tə bi ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz skʌl. wɪɹinəs hʌŋ ɑn ɪm laɪk ən aɪɝn weɪt.

To Rand the night seemed to last a year. All those eyes looking at him: Hake and Jak and Strom like vultures watching a sheep caught in a bog, Gode waiting like something even worse. He began to think that everybody in the room was watching with some hidden motive. Sour wine fumes and the stench of dirty, sweating bodies made his head swim, and the din of voices beat at him till his eyes blurred and even the sound of his own flute scratched at his ears. The crash of the thunder seemed to be inside his skull. Weariness hung on him like an iron weight.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðə nid tə bi ʌp wɪð ðə dɔn bɪɡæn tə pʊl mɛn ɹɪlʌktənli aʊɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹk. ə fɑɹmɝ hæɾ oʊnli hɪmsɛlf tə ænsɝ tə, bʌt mɝtʃəns wɝ noʊtɔɹiəsli ənfilɪŋ əbaʊt hæŋoʊvɝz wən ðeɪ wɝ peɪɪŋ dʒɹaɪvɝz' weɪdʒəz. ɪn ðə smɔl aʊɝz ðə kɑmən ɹum sloʊli ɛmptiɾ əz ivən ðoʊz u hæd ɹumz əbʌvstɛɹz stæɡɝɾ ɔf tə faɪn ðɛɹ bɛdz.

Eventually the need to be up with the dawn began to pull men reluctantly out into the dark. A farmer had only himself to answer to, but merchants were notoriously unfeeling about hangovers when they were paying drivers' wages. In the small hours the common room slowly emptied as even those who had rooms abovestairs staggered off to find their beds.

ɡoʊd wɑz ðə læs peɪtʃɹən. wən ɹænd ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə lɛðɝ flut keɪs, jɔnɪŋ, ɡoʊd stʊɾ ʌp ən slʌŋ ɪz kloʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ɑɹm. ðə sɝvɪŋ meɪdz wɝ klinɪŋ ʌp, mʌɾɝɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz əbaʊt ðə mɛs ə spɪld waɪn ən bɹoʊkən kɹɑkɝi. heɪk wɑz lɑkɪŋ ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ wɪð ə bɪɡ ki. ɡoʊd kɔɹnɝd heɪk fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ən heɪk kɔld wʌn ə ðə wɪmən tə ʃoʊ hɪm tə ə ɹum. ðə vɛlvət-kloʊk mæn ɡeɪv mæt ən ɹænd ə noʊɪŋ smaɪl bɪfɔɹ i dɪsəpɪɹɾ əpstɛɹz.

Gode was the last patron. When Rand reached for the leather flute case, yawning, Gode stood up and slung his cloak over his arm. The serving maids were cleaning up, muttering among themselves about the mess of spilled wine and broken crockery. Hake was locking the front door with a big key. Gode cornered Hake for a moment, and Hake called one of the women to show him to a room. The velvet-cloaked man gave Mat and Rand a knowing smile before he disappeared upstairs.

heɪk wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət ɹænd ən mæt. dʒæk ən stʃɹɑm stʊɾ əɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz.

Hake was looking at Rand and Mat. Jak and Strom stood at his shoulders.

ɹænd heɪstəli fɪnɪʃt hæŋɪŋ ɪz θɪŋz fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝz, hoʊldɪŋ əm ɔl ɔkwɝdli bɪhaɪn ɪm wɪð ɪz lɛf hæn soʊ hi kəd ɹitʃ ɪz sɔɹd. hi meɪd noʊ muv təwɔɹɾ ɪt, bʌɾ i wɑntəd tə noʊ ɪt wɑz ɹɛɾi. hi səpɹɛst ə jɔn; haʊ taɪɝɾ i wɑz wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ðeɪ ʃəd nɑt noʊ.

Rand hastily finished hanging his things from his shoulders, holding them all awkwardly behind him with his left hand so he could reach his sword. He made no move toward it, but he wanted to know it was ready. He suppressed a yawn; how tired he was was something they should not know.

mæt ʃoʊldɝɾ ɪz baʊ ən ɪz fju ʌðɝ bɪlɔŋɪŋz ɔkwɝdli, bʌɾ i pʊɾ ɪz hæn ʌndɝ ɪz koʊɾ əz i wɑtʃt heɪk ən ɪz tʌfs əpɹoʊtʃ.

Mat shouldered his bow and his few other belongings awkwardly, but he put his hand under his coat as he watched Hake and his toughs approach.

heɪk wɑz kæɹiɪŋ ən ɔɪl læmp, ən tə ɹændz sɝpɹaɪz i ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl baʊ ən dʒɛstʃɝd tə ə saɪd dɔɹ wɪð ɪt. "jɔɹ pæləts ɑɹ ðɪs weɪ." oʊnli ə slaɪt twɪst ə hɪz lɪps spɔɪld ɪz ækt.

Hake was carrying an oil lamp, and to Rand's surprise he gave a little bow and gestured to a side door with it. "Your pallets are this way." Only a slight twist of his lips spoiled his act.

mæt θɹʌst ɪz tʃɪn aʊɾ ət dʒæk ən stʃɹɑm. "ju nid ðoʊz tu tə ʃoʊ əs əɹ bɛdz?"

Mat thrust his chin out at Jak and Strom. "You need those two to show us our beds?"

"ɪm ə mæn ə pɹɑpɝɾi," heɪk sɛd, smuðɪŋ ðə fɹʌn ə hɪz sɔɪld eɪpɹən, "æn mɛn ə pɹɑpɝɾi kæn bi tu kɛɹfəl." ə kɹæʃ ə θʌndɝ ɹæɾəld ðə wɪndoʊz, ən i ɡlænst sɪɡnɪfɪkənli ət ðə silɪŋ, ðən ɡeɪv əm ə tuθi ɡɹɪn. "ju wɑnə si jəɹ bɛdz əɹ nɑt?"

"I'm a man of property," Hake said, smoothing the front of his soiled apron, "and men of property can't be too careful." A crash of thunder rattled the windows, and he glanced significantly at the ceiling, then gave them a toothy grin. "You want to see your beds or not?"

ɹænd wʌndɝd wʌt wəd hæpən ɪf i sɛd ðeɪ wɑntəd tə liv. ɪf jə ɹɪli dɪd noʊ mɔɹ əbaʊt juzɪŋ ə sɔɹd ðən ðə fju ɛksɝsaɪzəz læn ʃoʊd ju. . . . "lid ðə weɪ," hi sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ɪz vɔɪs hɑɹd. "aɪ doʊn laɪk hævɪŋ ɛnibəɾi bɪhaɪn mi."

Rand wondered what would happen if he said they wanted to leave. If you really did know more about using a sword than the few exercises Lan showed you. . . . "Lead the way," he said, trying to make his voice hard. "I don't like having anybody behind me."

stʃɹɑm snɪkɝd, bʌt heɪk nɑɾəd plɑtʃədli ən tɝn təwɔɹd ðə saɪd dɔɹ, ən ðə tu bɪɡ mɛn swæɡɝɾ æftɝ hɪm. teɪkɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, ɹænd ɡeɪv ə wɪʃfəl ɡlæns ət ðə dɔɹ tə ðə kɪtʃən. ɪf heɪk hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi lɑk ðə bæk dɔɹ, ɹʌnɪŋ naʊ wəɾ oʊnli bɪɡɪn wʌɾ i wɑz hoʊpɪŋ tə əvɔɪd. hi fɑloʊd ði ɪnkipɝ ɡlʌmli.

Strom snickered, but Hake nodded placidly and turned toward the side door, and the two big men swaggered after him. Taking a deep breath, Rand gave a wishful glance at the door to the kitchen. If Hake had already locked the back door, running now would only begin what he was hoping to avoid. He followed the innkeeper glumly.

ət ðə saɪd dɔɹ i hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ən mæt kɹaʊɾəd ɪndə hɪz bæk. ðə ɹizən fəɹ heɪks læmp wɑz əpɛɹənt. ðə dɔɹ lɛɾ ɪndə ə hɔl əz blæk əz pɪtʃ. oʊnli ðə læmp heɪk kæɹid, sɪləuɛɾɪŋ dʒæk ən stʃɹɑm, ɡeɪv ɪm ðə kɝədʒ tə kip ɑn. ɪf ðeɪ tɝnd, hi wəd noʊ ɪt. ən də wʌt? ðə flɔɹ kɹikt ʌndɝ ɪz buts.

At the side door he hesitated, and Mat crowded into his back. The reason for Hake's lamp was apparent. The door let into a hall as black as pitch. Only the lamp Hake carried, silhouetting Jak and Strom, gave him the courage to keep on. If they turned, he would know it. And do what? The floor creaked under his boots.

ðə hɔl ɛndəɾ ɪn ə ɹʌf, ənpeɪntɪd dɔɹ. hi hæd nɑt sin ɪf ðəɹ wɝ ɛni ʌðɝ dɔɹz əlɔŋ ðə weɪ. heɪk ən ɪz bʊliz wɛn θɹu, ən i fɑloʊd kwɪkli, bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kəɾ əv ə tʃæns tə sɛɾ ə tʃɹæp, bʌt heɪk mɪɹli lɪftəd ðə læmp haɪ ən dʒɛstʃɝɾ ət ðə ɹum.

The hall ended in a rough, unpainted door. He had not seen if there were any other doors along the way. Hake and his bullies went through, and he followed quickly, before they could have a chance to set a trap, but Hake merely lifted the lamp high and gestured at the room.

"hɪɹ ɪɾ ɪz."

"Here it is."

ən oʊl stɔɹɹum, hi hæd kɔld ɪt, ən baɪ ðə lʊk ʌv ɪt nɑt juzd ɪn səm taɪm. wɛðɝd bæɹəlz ən bɹoʊkən kɹeɪts fɪl hæf ðə flɔɹ. stɛɾi dʒɹɪps fɛl fɹəm mɔɹ ðən wʌn pleɪs ɑn ðə silɪŋ, ən ə bɹoʊkən peɪn ɪn ðə fɪlθi wɪndoʊ lɛt ðə ɹeɪn bloʊ ɪn fɹili. ʌnaɪɾentəfaɪəbəl ɑdz ən ɛnz lɪɾɝd ðə ʃɛlvz, ən θɪk dʌs kʌvɝɾ ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ðə pɹɛzəns ə ðə pɹɑməs pæləts wɑz ə sɝpɹaɪz.

An old storeroom, he had called it, and by the look of it not used in some time. Weathered barrels and broken crates filled half the floor. Steady drips fell from more than one place on the ceiling, and a broken pane in the filthy window let the rain blow in freely. Unidentifiable odds and ends littered the shelves, and thick dust covered almost everything. The presence of the promised pallets was a surprise.

ðə sɔɹd meɪks ɪm nɝvəs. hi woʊn tʃɹaɪ ɛniθɪŋ əntɪl wɝ saʊn əslip. ɹænd hæd noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə slipɪŋ ʌndɝ heɪks ɹuf. əz sun əz ði ɪnkipɝ lɛft, hi ɪntɛndəd tə bi aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ. "ɪɾəl du," hi sɛd. hi kɛpt ɪz aɪz ɑn heɪk, wɛɹi fəɹ ə sɪɡnəl tə ðə tu ɡɹɪnɪŋ mɛn ət ði ɪnkipɝz saɪd. ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt nɑt tə wɛɾ ɪz lɪps. "liv ðə læmp."

The sword makes him nervous. He won't try anything until we're sound asleep. Rand had no intention of sleeping under Hake's roof. As soon as the innkeeper left, he intended to be out the window. "It'll do," he said. He kept his eyes on Hake, wary for a signal to the two grinning men at the innkeeper's side. It was an effort not to wet his lips. "Leave the lamp."

heɪk ɡɹʌntɪd, bʌt pʊʃt ðə læmp ɑntu ə ʃɛlf. hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, lʊkɪŋ ət ðɛm, ən ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ i wɑz əbaʊt tə ɡɪv ðə wɝd fəɹ dʒæk ən stʃɹɑm tə dʒʌmp ðɛm, bʌɾ ɪz aɪz wɛn tə ɹændz sɔɹd wɪð ə kælkjəleɪɾɪŋ fɹaʊn, ən i dʒɝkt ɪz hɛɾ ət ðə tu bɪɡ mɛn. sɝpɹaɪz flæʃt əkɹɔs ðɛɹ bɹɔd feɪsəz, bʌt ðeɪ fɑloʊɾ ɪm aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum wɪθaʊɾ ə bækwɝd ɡlæns.

Hake grunted, but pushed the lamp onto a shelf. He hesitated, looking at them, and Rand was sure he was about to give the word for Jak and Strom to jump them, but his eyes went to Rand's sword with a calculating frown, and he jerked his head at the two big men. Surprise flashed across their broad faces, but they followed him out of the room without a backward glance.

ɹænd weɪɾəd fəɹ ðə kɹik-kɹik-kɹik ə ðɛɹ fʊtstɛps tə feɪɾ əweɪ, ðən kaʊntəd tə fɪfti bɪfɔɹ stɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɪndə ðə hɔl. ðə blæknəs wɑz bɹoʊkən oʊnli baɪ ə ɹɛktæŋɡəl ə laɪt ðət simd əz dɪstən əz ðə mun: ðə dɔɹ tə ðə kɑmən ɹum. əz i pʊld ɪz hɛɾ ɪn, sʌmθɪŋ bɪɡ muvd ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs nɪɹ ðə fɑɹ dɔɹ. dʒæk əɹ stʃɹɑm, stændɪŋ ɡɑɹd.

Rand waited for the creak-creak-creak of their footsteps to fade away, then counted to fifty before sticking his head into the hall. The blackness was broken only by a rectangle of light that seemed as distant as the moon: the door to the common room. As he pulled his head in, something big moved in the darkness near the far door. Jak or Strom, standing guard.

ə kwɪk ɪɡzæməneɪʃən ə ðə dɔɹ toʊld ɪm ɔl i niɾəd tə noʊ, lɪɾəl ʌv ɪt ɡʊd. ðə bɔɹdz wɝ θɪk ən staʊt, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ lɑk, ən noʊ bɑɹ ɑn ði ɪnsaɪd. ɪt dɪɾ oʊpən ɪndə ðə ɹum, ðoʊ.

A quick examination of the door told him all he needed to know, little of it good. The boards were thick and stout, but there was no lock, and no bar on the inside. It did open into the room, though.

"aɪ θɔt ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ fəɹ ʌs," mæt sɛd. "wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ weɪɾɪŋ fɔɹ?" hi hæd ðə dæɡɝ aʊt, ɡɹɪpt ɪn ə waɪt-nʌkəl fɪst. læmplaɪt flɪkɝɾ ɑn ðə bleɪd. hɪz baʊ ən kwɪvɝ leɪ fɝɡɑɾən ɑn ðə flɔɹ.

"I thought they were going for us," Mat said. "What are they waiting for?" He had the dagger out, gripped in a white-knuckled fist. Lamplight flickered on the blade. His bow and quiver lay forgotten on the floor.

"fɔɹ əs tə ɡoʊ tə slip." ɹænd stɑɹɾəd ɹʌmɪdʒɪŋ θɹu ðə bæɹəlz ən kɹeɪts. "hɛlp mi faɪn sʌmθɪŋ tə blɑk ðə dɔɹ."

"For us to go to sleep." Rand started rummaging through the barrels and crates. "Help me find something to block the door."

"waɪ? jə doʊn ɹɪli ɪntɛn tə slip hɪɹ, də ju? lɛts ɡɛɾ aʊt ðə wɪndoʊ ən ɡɔn. aɪd ɹæðɝ bi wɛt ðən dɛd."

"Why? You don't really intend to sleep here, do you? Let's get out the window and gone. I'd rather be wet than dead."

"wʌn ə ðɛm ɪz ət ði ɛn ə ðə hɔl. wi meɪk ɛni nɔɪz, ən ðəl bi daʊn ɑn əs bɪfɔɹ wi kən blɪŋk. aɪ θɪŋk heɪk wəd ɹæðɝ feɪs əs əweɪk ðən ɹɪsk lɛɾɪŋ əs ɡɛɾ əweɪ."

"One of them is at the end of the hall. We make any noise, and they'll be down on us before we can blink. I think Hake would rather face us awake than risk letting us get away."

mʌɾɝɪŋ, mæt dʒɔɪn ɪz sɝtʃ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ jusfəl ɪn ɛni ʌv ðə lɪɾɝ ɑn ðə flɔɹ. ðə bæɹəlz wɝ ɛmpti, ðə kɹeɪts splɪntɝd, ən ðə hoʊl lɑɾ ə ðɛm paɪld ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə dɔɹ wəd nɑt stɑp ɛniwʌn fɹəm oʊpənɪŋ ɪt. ðən sʌmθɪŋ fəmɪljɝ ɑn ə ʃɛlf kɑt ɹændz aɪ. tu splɪɾɪŋ wɛdʒəz, kʌvɝd wɪð ɹʌst ən dʌst. hi tʊk əm daʊn wɪð ə ɡɹɪn.

Muttering, Mat joined his search, but there was nothing useful in any of the litter on the floor. The barrels were empty, the crates splintered, and the whole lot of them piled in front of the door would not stop anyone from opening it. Then something familiar on a shelf caught Rand's eye. Two splitting wedges, covered with rust and dust. He took them down with a grin.

heɪstəli hi ʃʌvd əm ʌndɝ ðə dɔɹ ænd, wən ðə nɛkst ɹoʊl ə θʌndɝ ɹæɾəld ði ɪn, dʒɹoʊv əm ɪn wɪð tu kwɪk kɪks ə hɪz hil. ðə θʌndɝ feɪɾəd, ən i hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ, lɪsnɪŋ. ɔl i hɝd wɑz ðə ɹeɪn paʊndɪŋ ɑn ðə ɹuf. noʊ flɔɹbɔɹdz kɹikɪŋ ʌndɝ ɹʌnɪŋ fit.

Hastily he shoved them under the door and, when the next roll of thunder rattled the inn, drove them in with two quick kicks of his heel. The thunder faded, and he held his breath, listening. All he heard was the rain pounding on the roof. No floorboards creaking under running feet.

"ðə wɪndoʊ," hi sɛd.

"The window," he said.

ɪt hæd nɑt bɪn oʊpən ɪn jɪɹz, fɹəm ðə dɝt kɹʌstɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪt. ðeɪ stʃɹeɪn təɡɛðɝ, pʊʃɪŋ ʌp wɪð ɔl ðɛɹ maɪt. ɹændz niz wɑbəl bɪfɔɹ ðə sæʃ bʌdʒd; ɪt ɡɹoʊnd wɪð itʃ ɹɪlʌktən ɪntʃ. wən ði oʊpənɪŋ wɑz waɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ əm tə slɪp θɹu, hi kɹaʊtʃt, ðən stɑpt.

It had not been opened in years, from the dirt crusted around it. They strained together, pushing up with all their might. Rand's knees wobbled before the sash budged; it groaned with each reluctant inch. When the opening was wide enough for them to slip through, he crouched, then stopped.

"blʌɾ ən æʃəz!" mæt ɡɹaʊld. "noʊ wʌndɝ heɪk wɑznt wɝiɾ əbaʊɾ əs slɪpɪŋ aʊt."

"Blood and ashes!" Mat growled. "No wonder Hake wasn't worried about us slipping out."

aɪɝn bɑɹz ɪn ən aɪɝn fɹeɪm ɡlɪsənd wɛtli ɪn ðə laɪt fɹəm ðə læmp. ɹænd pʊʃt ət ðɛm; ðeɪ wɝ əz sɑləɾ əz ə boʊldɝ.

Iron bars in an iron frame glistened wetly in the light from the lamp. Rand pushed at them; they were as solid as a boulder.

"aɪ sɔ sʌmθɪŋ," mæt sɛd. hi pɔd hɝidli θɹu ðə lɪɾɝ ɑn ðə ʃɛlvz ən keɪm bæk wɪð ə ɹʌsti kɹoʊbɑɹ. hi ɹæm ði ɛn ʌv ɪɾ ʌndɝ ði aɪɝn fɹeɪm ɑn wʌn saɪd, ən ɹænd wɪnst.

"I saw something," Mat said. He pawed hurriedly through the litter on the shelves and came back with a rusty crowbar. He rammed the end of it under the iron frame on one side, and Rand winced.

"ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə nɔɪz, mæt."

"Remember the noise, Mat."

mæt ɡɹɪməst ən mʌɾɝd ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ, bʌɾ i weɪɾəd. ɹænd pʊɾ ɪz hænz ɑn ðə kɹoʊbɑɹ ən tʃɹaɪd tə faɪnd ɡʊd fʊɾɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡɹoʊɪŋ pʌɾəl ʌv wɔɾɝ ʌndɝ ðə wɪndoʊ. θʌndɝ ɹoʊld ən ðeɪ hivd. wɪð ə tɔɹtʃɝd skwil ə neɪlz ðət meɪd ðə hɛɹz lɪft ɑn ɹændz nɛk, ðə fɹeɪm ʃɪftəd - ə kɔɹɾɝ ʌv ən ɪntʃ, ɪf ðæt. taɪmɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz tə pilz ə θʌndɝ ən laɪtnɪŋ kɹæks, ðeɪ hivd ɑn ðə kɹoʊbɑɹ əɡɛn ən əɡɛn. nʌθɪŋ. ə kɔɹɾɝ ʌv ən ɪntʃ. nʌθɪŋ. ə hɛɹzbɹɛdθ. nʌθɪŋ. nʌθɪŋ.

Mat grimaced and muttered under his breath, but he waited. Rand put his hands on the crowbar and tried to find good footing in the growing puddle of water under the window. Thunder rolled and they heaved. With a tortured squeal of nails that made the hairs lift on Rand's neck, the frame shifted - a quarter of an inch, if that. Timing themselves to peals of thunder and lightning cracks, they heaved on the crowbar again and again. Nothing. A quarter of an inch. Nothing. A hairsbreadth. Nothing. Nothing.

sʌɾənli ɹændz fit slɪpt ɪn ðə wɔɾɝ, ən ðeɪ kɹæʃt tə ðə flɔɹ. ðə kɹoʊbɑɹ klæɾɝd əɡɛns ðə bɑɹz laɪk ə ɡɔŋ. hi leɪ ɪn ə pʌɾəl hoʊldɪŋ ɪz bɹɛθ ən lɪsnɪŋ. saɪləns bʌt fəɹ ðə ɹeɪn.

Suddenly Rand's feet slipped in the water, and they crashed to the floor. The crowbar clattered against the bars like a gong. He lay in a puddle holding his breath and listening. Silence but for the rain.

mæt nɝs bɹuz nʌkəlz ən ɡlɛɹɾ ət hɪm. "wil nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ aʊɾ ət ðɪs ɹeɪt." ði aɪɝn fɹeɪm wɑz pʊʃt aʊt fɹəm ðə wɪndoʊ nɑt kwaɪt fɑɹ ɪnʌf tə ɡɛt tu fɪŋɡɝz ʌndɝ ɪt. dʌzənz ə θɪk neɪlz kɹɔs ðə nɛɹoʊ oʊpənɪŋ.

Mat nursed bruised knuckles and glared at him. "We'll never get out at this rate." The iron frame was pushed out from the window not quite far enough to get two fingers under it. Dozens of thick nails crossed the narrow opening.

"wi dʒʌst əv tə kip tʃɹaɪɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd, ɡɛɾɪŋ ʌp. bʌɾ əz i sɛt ðə kɹoʊbɑɹ ʌndɝ ði ɛdʒ ə ðə fɹeɪm, ðə dɔɹ kɹikt əz sʌmwʌn tʃɹaɪd tə oʊpən ɪt. ðə splɪɾɪŋ wɛdʒəz hɛld ɪt ʃʌt. hi ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə wɝid lʊk wɪð mæt. mæt pʊl ðə dæɡɝ aʊɾ əɡɛn. ðə dɔɹ ɡeɪv ənʌðɝ skɹik.

"We just have to keep trying," Rand said, getting up. But as he set the crowbar under the edge of the frame, the door creaked as someone tried to open it. The splitting wedges held it shut. He exchanged a worried look with Mat. Mat pulled the dagger out again. The door gave another screak.

ɹænd tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən tʃɹaɪd tə meɪk ɪz vɔɪs stɛɾi. "ɡoʊ əweɪ, heɪk. wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə slip."

Rand took a deep breath and tried to make his voice steady. "Go away, Hake. We're trying to sleep."

"aɪ fɪɹ jə mɪsteɪk mi." ðə vɔɪs wɑz soʊ slik ən fʊl ʌv ɪtsɛlf ðəɾ ɪt neɪmd ɪts oʊnɝ. haʊəl ɡoʊd. "mæstɝ heɪk ən ɪz . . . mɪnjənz wɪl nɑt tʃɹʌbəl ʌs. ðeɪ slip saʊnli, ən ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ðəl oʊnli bi eɪbəl tə wʌndɝ wɛɹ jə vænɪʃt tə. lemi ɪn, maɪ jʌŋ fɹɛnz. wi mʌs tɔk."

"I fear you mistake me." The voice was so sleek and full of itself that it named its owner. Howal Gode. "Master Hake and his . . . minions will not trouble us. They sleep soundly, and in the morning they will only be able to wonder where you vanished to. Let me in, my young friends. We must talk."

"wi doʊn əv ɛniθɪŋ tə tɔk tə jə əbaʊt," mæt sɛd. "ɡoʊ əweɪ ən lɛɾ əs slip."

"We don't have anything to talk to you about," Mat said. "Go away and let us sleep."

ɡoʊdz tʃʌkəl wɑz næsti. "ʌv kɔɹs wɪv θɪŋz tə tɔk əbaʊt. jə noʊ ðəɾ əz wɛl əz aɪ. aɪ sɔ ɪɾ ɪn jəɹ aɪz. aɪ noʊ wʌt jə ɑɹ, pɝhæps bɛɾɝ ðən jə du. aɪ kən fil ɪt kʌmɪŋ fɹəm jə ɪn weɪvz. ɔlɹɛɾi jə hæfweɪ bɪlɔŋ tə maɪ mæstɝ. stɑp ɹʌnɪŋ ən æksɛpt ɪt. θɪŋz wɪl bi soʊ mʌtʃ iziɝ fəɹ ju. ɪf ðə tɑɹ vəlɑn hæɡz faɪn ju, jəl wɪʃ jə kəd kʌt jəɹ oʊn θɹoʊt bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ dʌn, bʌt jə woʊn bi eɪbəl tə. oʊnli maɪ mæstɝ kən pɹətɛk jə fɹəm ðɛm."

Gode's chuckle was nasty. "Of course we have things to talk about. You know that as well as I. I saw it in your eyes. I know what you are, perhaps better than you do. I can feel it coming from you in waves. Already you halfway belong to my master. Stop running and accept it. Things will be so much easier for you. If the Tar Valon hags find you, you'll wish you could cut your own throat before they are done, but you won't be able to. Only my master can protect you from them."

ɹænd swɑloʊd hɑɹd. "wi doʊnt noʊ wʌt jəɹ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt. liv əs əloʊn." ðə flɔɹbɔɹdz ɪn ðə hɔl skwikt. ɡoʊd wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn. haʊ mɛni mɛn kəɾ i hæv bɹɔɾ ɪn tu kæɹɪdʒɪz?

Rand swallowed hard. "We don't know what you're talking about. Leave us alone." The floorboards in the hall squeaked. Gode was not alone. How many men could he have brought in two carriages?

"stɑp biɪŋ fulɪʃ, maɪ jʌŋ fɹɛnz. jə noʊ. jə noʊ vɛɹi wɛl. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk əz mɑɹk jə fəɹ ɪz oʊn. ɪts ɹɪɾən ðət wən i əweɪks, ðə nu dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz wɪl bi ðəɹ tə pɹeɪz hɪm. jə mʌs bi tu ʌv ðɛm, ɛls aɪ wəd nɑɾ əv bɪn sɛn tə faɪn ju. θɪŋk ʌv ɪt. laɪf ɛvɝlæstɪŋ, ən paʊɝ bɪɑn dʒɹimz." hɪz vɔɪs wɑz θɪk wɪð hʌŋɡɝ fəɹ ðət paʊɝ hɪmsɛlf.

"Stop being foolish, my young friends. You know. You know very well. The Great Lord of the Dark has marked you for his own. It is written that when he awakes, the new Dreadlords will be there to praise him. You must be two of them, else I would not have been sent to find you. Think of it. Life everlasting, and power beyond dreams." His voice was thick with hunger for that power himself.

ɹænd ɡlæns bæk ət ðə wɪndoʊ dʒʌst əz laɪtnɪŋ splɪt ðə skaɪ, ən i ɔlmoʊst ɡɹoʊnd. ðə bɹif flæʃ ə laɪt ʃoʊd mɛn aʊtsaɪd, mɛn ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə ɹeɪn ðət dʒɹɛntʃt əm əz ðeɪ stʊd wɑtʃɪŋ ðə wɪndoʊ.

Rand glanced back at the window just as lightning split the sky, and he almost groaned. The brief flash of light showed men outside, men ignoring the rain that drenched them as they stood watching the window.

"aɪ taɪɝ ə ðɪs," ɡoʊɾ ənaʊnst. "ju wɪl səbmɪt tə maɪ mæstɝ - tə jəɹ mæstɝ - əɹ jəl bi meɪd tə səbmɪt. ðət wəd nɑt bi plɛzən fəɹ ju. ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk ɹulz dɛθ, ən i kən ɡɪv laɪf ɪn dɛθ əɹ dɛθ ɪn laɪf əz i tʃuzəz. oʊpən ðɪs dɔɹ. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ, jəɹ ɹʌnɪŋ ɪz əɾ ən ɛnd. oʊpən ɪt, aɪ seɪ!"

"I tire of this," Gode announced. "You will submit to my master - to your master - or you will be made to submit. That would not be pleasant for you. The Great Lord of the Dark rules death, and he can give life in death or death in life as he chooses. Open this door. One way or another, your running is at an end. Open it, I say!"

hi mʌst əv sɛd sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, tu, fəɹ sʌɾənli ə hɛvi bɑɾi θʌddɪɾ əɡɛns ðə dɔɹ. ɪt ʃɪvɝd, ən ðə wɛdʒəz slɪɾ ə fɹækʃən ʌv ən ɪntʃ wɪð ə ɡɹeɪɾ ə ɹʌst ɹʌbɪŋ ɔf ɑn wʊd. əɡɛn ən əɡɛn ðə dɔɹ tʃɹɛmbəld əz bɑɾiz hɝl ðɛmsɛlvz əɾ ɪt. səmtaɪmz ðə wɛdʒəz hɛld; səmtaɪmz ðeɪ slɪɾ ənʌðɝ taɪni bɪt, ən bɪt baɪ taɪni bɪt ðə dɔɹ kɹɛpt ɪnɛksɝəbli ɪnwɝd.

He must have said something else, too, for suddenly a heavy body thudded against the door. It shivered, and the wedges slid a fraction of an inch with a grate of rust rubbing off on wood. Again and again the door trembled as bodies hurled themselves at it. Sometimes the wedges held; sometimes they slid another tiny bit, and bit by tiny bit the door crept inexorably inward.

"səbmɪt," ɡoʊd dɪmændəd fɹəm ðə hɔl, "ɔɹ spɛn ɪtɝnəɾi wɪʃɪŋ ðət jə hæd!"

"Submit," Gode demanded from the hall, "or spend eternity wishing that you had!"

"ɪf wi doʊn əv ɛni tʃɔɪs - " mæt lɪkt ɪz lɪps ʌndɝ ɹændz stɛɹ. hɪz aɪz dɑɹɾɪd laɪk ði aɪz ʌv ə bædʒɝ ɪn ə tʃɹæp; hɪz feɪs wɑz peɪl, ən i pæntɪɾ əz i spoʊk. "wi kəd seɪ jɛs, ən ðən ɡɛɾ əweɪ leɪɾɝ. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, ɹænd, ðɛɹz noʊ weɪ aʊt!"

"If we don't have any choice - " Mat licked his lips under Rand's stare. His eyes darted like the eyes of a badger in a trap; his face was pale, and he panted as he spoke. "We could say yes, and then get away later. Blood and ashes, Rand, there's no way out!"

ðə wɝdz sim tə dʒɹɪf tə ɹænd θɹu wʊl stʌft ɪn ɪz ɪɹz. noʊ weɪ aʊt. θʌndɝ mʌɾɝd oʊvɝhɛd, ən wɑz dʒɹaʊn ɪn ə slæʃ ə laɪtnɪŋ. hæv tə faɪn ə weɪ aʊt. ɡoʊd kɔl tə ðɛm, dɪmændɪŋ, əpilɪŋ; ðə dɔɹ slɪɾ ənʌðɝ ɪntʃ təwɔɹd biɪŋ oʊpən. ə weɪ aʊt!

The words seemed to drift to Rand through wool stuffed in his ears. No way out. Thunder muttered overhead, and was drowned in a slash of lightning. Have to find a way out. Gode called to them, demanding, appealing; the door slid another inch toward being open. A way out!

laɪt fɪl ðə ɹum, flʌɾɪŋ vɪʒən; ði ɛɹ ɹɔɹɾ ən bɝnd. ɹænd fɛl hɪmsɛlf pɪkt ʌp ən dæʃt əɡɛns ðə wɔl. hi slɪd daʊn ɪn ə hip, ɪɹz ɹɪŋɪŋ ən ɛvɹi hɛɹ ɑn ɪz bɑɾi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə stæn ɑn ɛnd. deɪzd, hi stæɡɝd tə hɪz fit. hɪz niz wɑbəld, ən i pʊɾ ə hæn əɡɛns ðə wɔl tə stɛɾi hɪmsɛlf. hi lʊkt ɝaʊn ɪn əmeɪzmənt.

Light filled the room, flooding vision; the air roared and burned. Rand felt himself picked up and dashed against the wall. He slid down in a heap, ears ringing and every hair on his body trying to stand on end. Dazed, he staggered to his feet. His knees wobbled, and he put a hand against the wall to steady himself. He looked around in amazement.

ðə læmp, laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪts saɪɾ ɑn ði ɛdʒ ʌv wʌn ə ðə fju ʃɛlvz stɪl klɪŋɪŋ tə ðə wɔlz, stɪl bɝn ən ɡeɪv laɪt. ɔl ðə bæɹəlz ən kɹeɪts, səm blækən ən smoʊldɝɪŋ, leɪ tɑpəld wɛɹ ðeɪ hæd bɪn hɝld. ðə wɪndoʊ, bɑɹz ən ɔl, ən moʊst ə ðə wɔl, tu, hæd vænɪʃt, livɪŋ ə splɪntɝd hoʊl. ðə ɹuf sæɡd, ən tɛnʒɹəlz ə smoʊk fɔt ðə ɹeɪn ɝaʊn ðə dʒæɡd ɛdʒəz ə ði oʊpənɪŋ. ðə dɔɹ hʌŋ ɔf ɪts hɪnʒɪz, dʒæmd ɪn ðə dɔɹfɹeɪm əɾ ən æŋɡəl slæntɪŋ ɪndə ðə hɔl.

The lamp, lying on its side on the edge of one of the few shelves still clinging to the walls, still burned and gave light. All the barrels and crates, some blackened and smoldering, lay toppled where they had been hurled. The window, bars and all, and most of the wall, too, had vanished, leaving a splintered hole. The roof sagged, and tendrils of smoke fought the rain around the jagged edges of the opening. The door hung off its hinges, jammed in the doorframe at an angle slanting into the hall.

wɪð ə filɪŋ ʌv wuzi ʌnɹiæləɾi hi stʊd ðə læmp ʌp. ɪt sim ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld wɑz meɪkɪŋ ʃʊɹ ɪt dɪd nɑt bɹeɪk.
