With a feeling of woozy unreality he stood the lamp up. It seemed the most important thing in the world was making sure it did not break.

ə paɪl ə kɹeɪts sʌɾənli hivd əpɑɹt, ən mæt stʊɾ ʌp ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪt. hi wivd ɑn ɪz fit, blɪŋkɪŋ ən fʌmbəlɪŋ ət hɪmsɛlf əz ɪf wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz stɪl ətætʃt. hi pɪɹd təwɔɹd ɹænd. "ɹænd? ɪz ðət ju? jəɹ əlaɪv. aɪ θɔt wi wɝ boʊθ - " hi bɹoʊk ɔf, baɪɾɪŋ ɪz lɪp ən ʃeɪkɪŋ. ɪt tʊk ɹænd ə moʊmən tə ɹilaɪz i wɑz læfɪŋ, ən ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɪstɛɹiə.

A pile of crates suddenly heaved apart, and Mat stood up in the middle of it. He weaved on his feet, blinking and fumbling at himself as if wondering if everything was still attached. He peered toward Rand. "Rand? Is that you? You're alive. I thought we were both - " He broke off, biting his lip and shaking. It took Rand a moment to realize he was laughing, and on the edge of hysteria.

"wʌt hæpənd, mæt? mæt? mæt! wʌt hæpənd?"

"What happened, Mat? Mat? Mat! What happened?"

wʌn læst ʃɪvɝ ɹæk mæt, ən ðən i wɑz stɪl. "laɪtnɪŋ, ɹænd. aɪ wɑz lʊkɪŋ ɹaɪɾ ət ðə wɪndoʊ wən ɪt hɪt ðə bɑɹz. laɪtnɪŋ. aɪ kæn si wɝθ - " hi bɹoʊk ɔf, skwɪntɪŋ ət ði æslɑn dɔɹ, ən ɪz vɔɪs wɛnt ʃɑɹp. "wɛɹz ɡoʊd?"

One last shiver wracked Mat, and then he was still. "Lightning, Rand. I was looking right at the window when it hit the bars. Lightning. I can't see worth - " He broke off, squinting at the aslant door, and his voice went sharp. "Where's Gode?"

nʌθɪŋ muvd ɪn ðə dɑɹk kɔɹəɾɝ bɪɑn ðə dɔɹ. ʌv ɡoʊɾ ən ɪz kəmpænjənz ðəɹ wɑz niðɝ saɪn nɔɹ saʊnd, ðoʊ ɛniθɪŋ cʊɾə leɪn ɪn ðə blæknəs. ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf hoʊpɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ dɛd, bʌɾ i wəd nɑɾ əv pʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɪndə ðə hɔl tə faɪn aʊt fəɹ ʃʊɹ ɪf i hæd bɪn ɔfɝɾ ə kɹaʊn. nʌθɪŋ muvd aʊɾ ɪn ðə naɪt bɪɑnd wɛɹ ðə wɔl hæd bɪn, iðɝ, bʌɾ ʌðɝz wɝ ʌp ən əbaʊt. kənfjuzd ʃaʊts keɪm fɹəm əbʌvstɛɹz ɪn ði ɪn, ən ðə paʊndɪŋ ə ɹʌnɪŋ fit.

Nothing moved in the dark corridor beyond the door. Of Gode and his companions there was neither sign nor sound, though anything could have lain in the blackness. Rand found himself hoping they were dead, but he would not have put his head into the hall to find out for sure if he had been offered a crown. Nothing moved out in the night beyond where the wall had been, either, but others were up and about. Confused shouts came from abovestairs in the inn, and the pounding of running feet.

"lɛts ɡoʊ waɪl wi kæn," ɹænd sɛd.

"Let's go while we can," Rand said.

heɪstəli hɛlpɪŋ sɛpɝeɪt ðɛɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz fɹəm ðə ɹʌbəl, hi ɡɹæb mæts ɑɹm ən hæf pʊld, hæf ɡaɪɾəd ɪz fɹɛn θɹu ðə ɡeɪpɪŋ hoʊl ɪndə ðə naɪt. mæt klʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm, stʌmbəlɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪm wɪð ɪz hɛd pʊʃt fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ən ɛfɝt tə si.

Hastily helping separate their belongings from the rubble, he grabbed Mat's arm and half pulled, half guided his friend through the gaping hole into the night. Mat clutched his arm, stumbling beside him with his head pushed forward in an effort to see.

əz ðə fɝst ɹeɪn hɪt ɹændz feɪs, laɪtnɪŋ fɔɹkt əbʌv ði ɪn, ən i keɪm tə ə kənvʌlsɪv stɑp. ɡoʊdz mɛn wɝ stɪl ðɛɹ, laɪɪŋ wɪð ðɛɹ fit təwɔɹd ði oʊpənɪŋ. pɛltɪd baɪ ðə ɹeɪn, ðɛɹ oʊpən aɪz stɛɹɾ ət ðə skaɪ.

As the first rain hit Rand's face, lightning forked above the inn, and he came to a convulsive stop. Gode's men were still there, lying with their feet toward the opening. Pelted by the rain, their open eyes stared at the sky.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" mæt æskt. "blʌɾ ən æʃəz! aɪ kən hɑɹdli si maɪ oʊn blʌɾi hænd!"

"What is it?" Mat asked. "Blood and ashes! I can hardly see my own bloody hand!"

"nʌθɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd. lʌk. ðə laɪts oʊn. . . . ɪz ɪt? ʃɪvɝɪŋ, hi kɛɹfəli ɡaɪɾəd mæt ɝaʊn ðə bɑɾiz. "dʒʌs ðə laɪtnɪŋ."

"Nothing," Rand said. Luck. The Light's own. . . . Is it? Shivering, he carefully guided Mat around the bodies. "Just the lightning."

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ laɪt seɪv ðə laɪtnɪŋ, ən i stʌmbəld ɪn ðə ɹʌts əz ðeɪ ɹæn stæɡɝɪŋ əweɪ fɹəm ði ɪn. wɪð mæt ɔlmoʊs hæŋɪŋ ɑn hɪm, ɛvɹi stʌmbəl ɔlmoʊs pʊld əm boʊθ daʊn, bʌt tɑɾɝɪŋ, pæntɪŋ, ðeɪ ɹæn.

There was no light save the lightning, and he stumbled in the ruts as they ran staggering away from the inn. With Mat almost hanging on him, every stumble almost pulled them both down, but tottering, panting, they ran.

wʌns i lʊk bæk. wʌns, bɪfɔɹ ðə ɹeɪn θɪkən tə ə dɛfənɪŋ kɝɾən ðət blɑɾɪd ðə dænsɪŋ kɑɹtmən fɹəm saɪt. laɪtnɪŋ sɪləuɛɾɪd ðə fɪɡjɝ ʌv ə mæn ət ðə bæk ə ði ɪn, ə mæn ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz fɪst ət ðɛm, əɹ ət ðə skaɪ. ɡoʊɾ əɹ heɪk, hi dɪd nɑt noʊ, bʌɾ iðɝ wʌn wɑz əz bæɾ əz ði ʌðɝ. ðə ɹeɪn keɪm ɪn ə dɛljudʒ, aɪsəleɪɾɪŋ əm ɪn ə wɔl ʌv wɔɾɝ. hi hɝid θɹu ðə naɪt, lɪsnɪŋ θɹu ðə ɹɔɹ ə ðə stɔɹm fəɹ ðə saʊn ə pɝsut.

Once he looked back. Once, before the rain thickened to a deafening curtain that blotted The Dancing Cartman from sight. Lightning silhouetted the figure of a man at the back of the inn, a man shaking his fist at them, or at the sky. Gode or Hake, he did not know, but either one was as bad as the other. The rain came in a deluge, isolating them in a wall of water. He hurried through the night, listening through the roar of the storm for the sound of pursuit.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾiθɹi


CHAPTER 33

ðə dɑɹk weɪts


The Dark Waits

ʌndɝ ə lɛɾən skaɪ ðə haɪ-wil kɑɹt bʌmpt ist əlɔŋ ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd. ɹænd pʊl hɪmsɛlf aʊɾ ə ðə stʃɹɔ ɪn bæk tə lʊk oʊvɝ ðə saɪd. ɪt wɑz iziɝ ðən ɪt hæd bɪn ən aʊɝ ɝliɝ. hɪz ɑɹmz fɛlt əz ɪf ðeɪ maɪt stʃɹɛtʃ ɪnstɛɾ ə dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪm ʌp, ən fəɹ ə mɪnuɾ ɪz hɛd wɑntəd tə kip ɑn ɡoʊɪŋ ən floʊɾ əweɪ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz iziɝ. hi hʊkt ɪz ɛlboʊz oʊvɝ ðə loʊ slæts ən wɑtʃt ðə læn ɹoʊl pæst. ðə sʌn, stɪl hɪɾən baɪ dʌl klaʊdz, jɛt stʊd haɪ oʊvɝhɛd, bʌt ðə kɑɹt wɑz klæɾɝɪŋ ɪndə ənʌðɝ vɪlədʒ ə vaɪn-kʌvɝd, ɹɛd bɹɪk haʊsəz. taʊnz hæd bɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ kloʊsɝ təɡɛðɝ sɪns fɔɹ kɪŋz.

Under a leaden sky the high-wheeled cart bumped east along the Caemlyn Road. Rand pulled himself out of the straw in back to look over the side. It was easier than it had been an hour earlier. His arms felt as if they might stretch instead of drawing him up, and for a minute his head wanted to keep on going and float away, but it was easier. He hooked his elbows over the low slats and watched the land roll past. The sun, still hidden by dull clouds, yet stood high overhead, but the cart was clattering into another village of vine-covered, red brick houses. Towns had been getting closer together since Four Kings.

səm ə ðə pipəl weɪvd əɹ kɔld ə ɡɹiɾɪŋ tə haɪəm kɪntʃ, ðə fɑɹmɝ huz kɑɹɾ ɪt wɑz. mæstɝ kɪntʃ, lɛðɝi-feɪst ən tæsɪtɝn, ʃaʊɾəd bæk ə fju wɝdz itʃ taɪm, ɝaʊn ðə paɪp ɪn ɪz tiθ. ðə klɛntʃt tiθ meɪd wʌɾ i sɛɾ ɔl bʌɾ ʌnɪntɛlədʒəbəl, bʌɾ ɪt saʊndəd dʒoʊviəl ən sim tə sæɾəsfaɪ; ðeɪ wɛn bæk tə wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ ɡlæns ət ðə kɑɹt. noʊ wʌn əpɪɹd tə peɪ ɛni maɪn tə ðə fɑɹmɝz tu pæsənʒɝz.

Some of the people waved or called a greeting to Hyam Kinch, the farmer whose cart it was. Master Kinch, leathery-faced and taciturn, shouted back a few words each time, around the pipe in his teeth. The clenched teeth made what he said all but unintelligible, but it sounded jovial and seemed to satisfy; they went back to what they were doing without another glance at the cart. No one appeared to pay any mind to the farmer's two passengers.

ðə vɪlədʒ ɪn muv θɹu ɹændz fild ə vɪʒən. ɪt wɑz waɪtwɑʃt, wɪð ə ɡɹeɪ sleɪt ɹuf. pipəl bʌsəld ɪn ən aʊt, nɑɾɪŋ kæʒəwəli ən weɪvɪŋ tə wʌn ənʌðɝ. səm ə ðɛm stɑp tə spik. ðeɪ nu wʌn ənʌðɝ. vɪlɪdʒɝz, moʊsli, baɪ ðɛɹ kloʊðz - buts ən tʃɹaʊzɝz ən koʊts nɑt mʌtʃ dɪfɹən fɹəm wʌɾ i wɔɹ hɪmsɛlf, ðoʊ wɪð ən ɪnɔɹɾənɪt fɑndnəs fəɹ kʌlɝfəl stʃɹaɪps. ðə wɪmən wɔɹ dip bɑnəts ðət hɪd ðɛɹ feɪsəz ən waɪɾ eɪpɹənz wɪð stʃɹaɪps. meɪbi ðeɪ wɝ ɔl taʊnsmɪn ən loʊkəl fɑɹmfoʊk. dʌz ðət meɪk ɛni dɪfɝəns?

The village inn moved through Rand's field of vision. It was whitewashed, with a gray slate roof. People bustled in and out, nodding casually and waving to one another. Some of them stopped to speak. They knew one another. Villagers, mostly, by their clothes - boots and trousers and coats not much different from what he wore himself, though with an inordinate fondness for colorful stripes. The women wore deep bonnets that hid their faces and white aprons with stripes. Maybe they were all townsmen and local farmfolk. Does that make any difference?

hi dʒɹɑp bæk ɑn ðə stʃɹɔ, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə vɪlədʒ dwɪndəl bɪtwin ɪz fit. fɛns filz ən tʃɹɪm hɛdʒɪz laɪn ðə ɹoʊd, ən smɔl fɑɹmhaʊsəz wɪð smoʊk ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ɹɛd bɹɪk tʃɪmniz. ði oʊnli wʊdz nɪɹ ðə ɹoʊd wɝ kɑpɪsɪz, wɛl tɛndəd fəɹ faɪɝwʊd, teɪm əz ə fɑɹmjɑɹd. bʌt ðə bɹæntʃəz stʊd lifləs əɡɛns ðə skaɪ, əz stɑɹk əz ɪn ðə waɪld wʊdz tə ðə wɛst.

He dropped back on the straw, watching the village dwindle between his feet. Fenced fields and trimmed hedges lined the road, and small farmhouses with smoke rising from red brick chimneys. The only woods near the road were coppices, well tended for firewood, tame as a farmyard. But the branches stood leafless against the sky, as stark as in the wild woods to the west.

ə laɪn ʌv wæɡənz hɛɾɪŋ ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɹʌmbəl daʊn ðə sɛntɝ ə ðə ɹoʊd, kɹaʊɾɪŋ ðə kɑɹɾ oʊvɝ ɑntu ðə vɝdʒ. mæstɝ kɪntʃ ʃɪftəɾ ɪz paɪp tə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz maʊθ ən spæt bɪtwin ɪz tiθ. wɪð wʌn aɪ ɑn ɪz ɔf-saɪd wil, tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ɪt dɪd nɑt tæŋɡəl ɪn ðə hɛdʒ, hi kɛp ðə kɑɹt muvɪŋ. hɪz maʊθ taɪɾənd əz i ɡlænst ət ðə mɝtʃəns' tʃɹeɪn.

A line of wagons heading the other way rumbled down the center of the road, crowding the cart over onto the verge. Master Kinch shifted his pipe to the corner of his mouth and spat between his teeth. With one eye on his off-side wheel, to make sure it did not tangle in the hedge, he kept the cart moving. His mouth tightened as he glanced at the merchants' train.

nʌn ə ðə wæɡən dʒɹaɪvɝz kɹækɪŋ ðɛɹ lɔŋ wɪps ɪn ði ɛɹ əbʌv eɪt-hɔɹs timz, nʌn ə ðə hɑɹd-feɪst ɡɑɹdz slaʊtʃɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz əlɔŋsaɪd ðə wæɡənz, lʊkt ət ðə kɑɹt. ɹænd wɑtʃt əm ɡoʊ, hɪz tʃɛs taɪt. hɪz hænd wɑz ʌndɝ ɪz kloʊk, ɡɹɪpɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt, əntɪl ðə læst wæɡən lɝtʃt baɪ.

None of the wagon drivers cracking their long whips in the air above eight-horse teams, none of the hard-faced guards slouching in their saddles alongside the wagons, looked at the cart. Rand watched them go, his chest tight. His hand was under his cloak, gripping his sword hilt, until the last wagon lurched by.

əz ðət faɪnəl wæɡən ɹæɾəld əweɪ təwɔɹd ðə vɪlədʒ ðeɪ hæd dʒʌs lɛft, mæt tɝn ɑn ðə sit bɪsaɪd ðə fɑɹmɝ ən lin bæk əntɪl i faʊn ɹændz aɪz. ðə skɑɹf ðət dɪd duɾi fəɹ dʌst, wən nid bi, ʃeɪɾɪd ɪz oʊn aɪz, foʊldəɾ oʊvɝ θɪkli ən taɪd loʊ ɝaʊn ɪz fɔɹhɛd. ivən soʊ hi skwɪntɪɾ ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪ deɪlaɪt. "ju si ɛniθɪŋ bæk ðɛɹ?" hi æskt kwaɪətli. "wʌɾ əbaʊt ðə wæɡənz?"

As that final wagon rattled away toward the village they had just left, Mat turned on the seat beside the farmer and leaned back until he found Rand's eyes. The scarf that did duty for dust, when need be, shaded his own eyes, folded over thickly and tied low around his forehead. Even so he squinted in the gray daylight. "You see anything back there?" he asked quietly. "What about the wagons?"

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ən mæt nɑɾəd. hi hæd sin nʌθɪŋ iðɝ.

Rand shook his head, and Mat nodded. He had seen nothing either.

mæstɝ kɪntʃ ɡlænst əɾ əm aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, ðən ʃɪftəɾ ɪz paɪp əɡɛn, ən flæp ðə ɹeɪnz. ðət wɑz ɔl, bʌɾ i hæd noʊɾəst. ðə hɔɹs pɪkt ʌp ðə peɪs ə stɛp.

Master Kinch glanced at them out of the corner of his eye, then shifted his pipe again, and flapped the reins. That was all, but he had noticed. The horse picked up the pace a step.

"jɔɹ aɪz stɪl hɝt?" ɹænd æskt.

"Your eyes still hurt?" Rand asked.

mæt tʌtʃt ðə skɑɹf ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd. "noʊ. nɑt mʌtʃ. nɑɾ ənlɛs aɪ lʊk ɔlmoʊst ɹaɪɾ ət ðə sʌn, ɛniweɪ. wʌɾ əbaʊt ju? ɑɹ jə filɪŋ ɛni bɛɾɝ?"

Mat touched the scarf around his head. "No. Not much. Not unless I look almost right at the sun, anyway. What about you? Are you feeling any better?"

"sʌm." hi ɹɪli wɑz filɪŋ bɛɾɝ, hi ɹilaɪzd. ɪt wɑz ə wʌndɝ tə ɡɛɾ oʊvɝ biɪŋ sɪk soʊ fæst. mɔɹ ðən ðæt, ɪt wɑz ə ɡɪft ə ðə laɪt. ɪts tə bi ðə laɪt. ɪts tə bi.

"Some." He really was feeling better, he realized. It was a wonder to get over being sick so fast. More than that, it was a gift of the Light. It has to be the Light. It has to be.

sʌɾənli ə bɑɾi ʌv hɔɹsmən wɑz pæsɪŋ ðə kɑɹt, hɛɾɪŋ wɛs laɪk ðə mɝtʃəns' wæɡənz. lɔŋ waɪt kɑlɝz hʌŋ daʊn oʊvɝ ðɛɹ meɪl ən pleɪt, ən ðɛɹ kloʊks ən ʌndɝkoʊts wɝ ɹɛd, laɪk ðə ɡəttɛndɝz' junəfɔɹmz ɪn waɪtbɹɪdʒ, bʌt bɛɾɝ meɪɾ ən bɛɾɝ fɪɾɪŋ. itʃ mænz kɑnɪkəl hɛlmət ʃoʊn laɪk sɪlvɝ. ðeɪ sæt ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz wɪð stʃɹeɪt bæks. θɪn ɹɛd stʃɹimɝz flʌɾɝd bɪniθ ðə hɛdz ə ðɛɹ lænsɪz, ɛvɹi læns hɛld ət ðə seɪm æŋɡəl.

Suddenly a body of horsemen was passing the cart, heading west like the merchants' wagons. Long white collars hung down over their mail and plate, and their cloaks and undercoats were red, like the gatetenders' uniforms in Whitebridge, but better made and better fitting. Each man's conical helmet shone like silver. They sat their horses with straight backs. Thin red streamers fluttered beneath the heads of their lances, every lance held at the same angle.

səm ə ðɛm ɡlænst ɪndə ðə kɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ pæst ɪn tu kɑləmz. ə keɪdʒ ə stil bɑɹz mæskt itʃ feɪs. ɹænd wɑz ɡlæɾ ɪz kloʊk kʌvɝɾ ɪz sɔɹd. ə fju nɑɾəd tə mæstɝ kɪntʃ, nɑɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ nu hɪm, bʌɾ ɪn ə nutʃɹəl ɡɹiɾɪŋ. mæstɝ kɪntʃ nɑɾəd bæk ɪn mʌtʃ ðə seɪm weɪ, bʌt dɪspaɪɾ ɪz əntʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɪkspɹɛʃən ðəɹ wɑz ə hɪn ʌv əpɹuvəl ɪn ɪz nɑd.

Some of them glanced into the cart as they passed in two columns. A cage of steel bars masked each face. Rand was glad his cloak covered his sword. A few nodded to Master Kinch, not as if they knew him, but in a neutral greeting. Master Kinch nodded back in much the same way, but despite his unchanging expression there was a hint of approval in his nod.

ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz wɝ əɾ ə wɔk, bʌt wɪð ðə spiɾ ə ðə kɑɹɾ æɾəd, ðeɪ wɛn baɪ kwɪkli. wɪð ə pɑɹɾ ə hɪz maɪn ɹænd kaʊntəd ðɛm. tɛn . . . twɛnti . . . θɝɾi . . . θɝɾi-tu. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛd tə wɑtʃ ðə kɑləmz muv ɑn daʊn ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd.

Their horses were at a walk, but with the speed of the cart added, they went by quickly. With a part of his mind Rand counted them. Ten . . . twenty . . . thirty . . . thirty-two. He raised his head to watch the columns move on down the Caemlyn Road.

"hu wɝ ðeɪ?" mæt æskt, hæf wʌndɝɪŋ, hæf səspɪʃəs.

"Who were they?" Mat asked, half wondering, half suspicious.

"kwinz ɡɑɹdz," mæstɝ kɪntʃ sɛɾ ɝaʊn ɪz paɪp. hi kɛpt ɪz aɪz ɑn ðə ɹoʊɾ əhɛd. "woʊnt ɡoʊ mʌtʃ fɝðɝ ðən bɹinz spɹɪŋ, 'lɛs ðəɹ kɔl fɔɹ. nɑt laɪk ði oʊl deɪz." hi sʌkt ɑn ɪz paɪp, ðən æɾəd, "aɪ səpoʊz, ðiz deɪz, ðɛɹz pɑɹts ə ðə ɹɛlm doʊn si ðə ɡɑɹdz ɪn ə jɪɹ əɹ mɔɹ. nɑt laɪk ði oʊl deɪz."

"Queen's Guards," Master Kinch said around his pipe. He kept his eyes on the road ahead. "Won't go much further than Breen's Spring, 'less they're called for. Not like the old days." He sucked on his pipe, then added, "I suppose, these days, there's parts of the Realm don't see the Guards in a year or more. Not like the old days."

"wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ duɪŋ?" ɹænd æskt.

"What are they doing?" Rand asked.

ðə fɑɹmɝ ɡeɪv ɪm ə lʊk. "kipɪŋ ðə kwinz pis ən əphoʊldɪŋ ðə kwinz lɔ." hi nɑɾəd tə hɪmsɛlf əz ɪf i laɪk ðə saʊn ə ðæt, ən æɾəd, "sɝtʃɪŋ aʊt mæləfæktɝz ən siɪŋ əm bɪfɔɹ ə mædʒəstʃɹeɪt. mf!" hi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ stʃɹimɝ ə smoʊk. "ju tu mʌs bi fɹəm pɹɪɾi fɑɹ ɔf nɑt tə ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd. wɛɹ jə fɹʌm?"

The farmer gave him a look. "Keeping the Queen's peace and upholding the Queen's law." He nodded to himself as if he liked the sound of that, and added, "Searching out malefactors and seeing them before a magistrate. Mmmph!" He let out a long streamer of smoke. "You two must be from pretty far off not to recognize the Queen's Guard. Where you from?"

"fɑɹ ɔf," mæt sɛɾ ət ðə seɪm ɪnstən ðət ɹænd sɛd, "ðə tu ɹɪvɝz." hi wɪʃt i kəd teɪk ɪt bæk əz sun əz i sɛɾ ɪt. hi stɪl wɑz nɑt θɪŋkɪŋ klɪɹli. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə haɪd, ən mɛnʃənɪŋ ə neɪm ə feɪd wəd hɪɹ laɪk ə bɛl.

"Far off," Mat said at the same instant that Rand said, "The Two Rivers." He wished he could take it back as soon as he said it. He still was not thinking clearly. Trying to hide, and mentioning a name a Fade would hear like a bell.

mæstɝ kɪntʃ ɡlænst ət mæt aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ, ən pʌft ɪz paɪp ɪn saɪləns fəɹ ə waɪl. "ðæts fɑɹ ɔf, ɔl ɹaɪt," hi sɛd faɪnəli. "ɔlmoʊs tə ðə bɔɹɾɝ ə ðə ɹɛlm. bʌt θɪŋz mʌs bi wɝs ðən aɪ θɔɾ ɪf ðɛɹz pleɪsəz ɪn ðə ɹɛlm wɛɹ pipəl doʊn ivən ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz. nɑt laɪk ði oʊl deɪz əɾ ɔl."

Master Kinch glanced at Mat out of the corner of his eye, and puffed his pipe in silence for a while. "That's far off, all right," he said finally. "Almost to the border of the Realm. But things must be worse than I thought if there's places in the Realm where people don't even recognize the Queen's Guards. Not like the old days at all."

ɹænd wʌndɝd wʌt mæstɝ ælvɪɹ wəd seɪ ɪf sʌmwʌn toʊld ɪm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɑz pɑɹɾ ə səm kwinz ɹɛlm. ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ, hi səpoʊzd. pɝhæps ðə meɪɝ dɪd noʊ - hi nu ə lɑɾ ə θɪŋz ðət sɝpɹaɪzd ɹænd - ən meɪbi ʌðɝz dɪd, tu, bʌɾ i hæd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ɛniwʌn mɛnʃən ɪt. ðə tu ɹɪvɝz wɑz ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. itʃ vɪlədʒ hændəld ɪts oʊn pɹɑbləmz, ən ɪf səm dɪfəkəlti ɪnvɑlv mɔɹ ðən wʌn vɪlədʒ ðə meɪɝz, ən meɪbi ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəlz, sɑlvd ɪt bɪtwin ðɛm.

Rand wondered what Master al'Vere would say if someone told him the Two Rivers was part of some Queen's Realm. The Queen of Andor, he supposed. Perhaps the Mayor did know - he knew a lot of things that surprised Rand - and maybe others did, too, but he had never heard anyone mention it. The Two Rivers was the Two Rivers. Each village handled its own problems, and if some difficulty involved more than one village the Mayors, and maybe the Village Councils, solved it between them.

mæstɝ kɪntʃ pʊld ɑn ðə ɹeɪnz, dʒɹɔɪŋ ðə kɑɹt tə ə hɔlt. "fɑɹ əz aɪ ɡoʊ." ə nɛɹoʊ kɑɹt pæθ lɛɾ ɔf tə ðə nɔɹθ; sɛvɹəl fɑɹmhaʊsəz wɝ vɪzəbəl ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən əkɹɔs oʊpən filz, plaʊd bʌt stɪl bɛɹ ə kɹɑps. "tu deɪz wɪl si jə ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. list, ɪt wəɾ ɪf jəɹ fɹɛn hæɾ ɪz lɛɡz ʌndɝ hɪm."

Master Kinch pulled on the reins, drawing the cart to a halt. "Far as I go." A narrow cart path led off to the north; several farmhouses were visible in that direction across open fields, plowed but still bare of crops. "Two days will see you in Caemlyn. Least, it would if your friend had his legs under him."

mæt hɑp daʊn ən ɹitʃɹivd ɪz baʊ ən ʌðɝ θɪŋz, ðən hɛlpt ɹænd klaɪm ɔf ðə teɪl ə ðə kɑɹt. ɹændz bʌndəlz weɪɾ ɑn hɪm, ən ɪz lɛɡz wɑbəld, bʌɾ i ʃɹʌɡd ɔf ɪz fɹɛnz hæn ən tʃɹaɪɾ ə fju stɛps ɑn ɪz oʊn. hi stɪl fɛlt ənstɛɾi, bʌɾ ɪz lɛɡz hɛld ɪm ʌp. ðeɪ ivən sim tə ɡɹoʊ stʃɹɔŋɝ əz i juz ðɛm.

Mat hopped down and retrieved his bow and other things, then helped Rand climb off the tail of the cart. Rand's bundles weighed on him, and his legs wobbled, but he shrugged off his friend's hand and tried a few steps on his own. He still felt unsteady, but his legs held him up. They even seemed to grow stronger as he used them.

ðə fɑɹmɝ dɪd nɑt stɑɹɾ ɪz hɔɹs ʌp əɡɛn ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. hi stʌɾid əm fəɹ ə mɪnət, sʌkɪŋ ɑn ɪz paɪp. "ju kən ɹɛst ʌp ə deɪ əɹ tu ət maɪ pleɪs, ɪf jə wɑnt. woʊn mɪs ɛniθɪŋ ɪn ðət taɪm, aɪ səpoʊz. wʌtɛvɝ sɪknəs jəɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ oʊvɝ, jʌŋ fɛloʊ . . . wɛl, ði oʊld wʊmən ən mi, wi ɔlɹɛɾi hæɾ əbaʊɾ ɛvɹi sɪknəs jə kən θɪŋk ə bɪfɔɹ jə wɝ bɔɹn, ən nɝst əɹ jʌŋɡəlɪŋz θɹu 'ɛm, tu. aɪ ɪkspɛk jəɹ pæs ðə kætʃɪŋ steɪdʒ, ɛniweɪ."

The farmer did not start his horse up again right away. He studied them for a minute, sucking on his pipe. "You can rest up a day or two at my place, if you want. Won't miss anything in that time, I suppose. Whatever sickness you're getting over, young fellow . . . well, the old woman and me, we already had about every sickness you can think of before you were born, and nursed our younglings through 'em, too. I expect you're past the catching stage, anyway."

mæts aɪz nɛɹoʊd, ən ɹænd kɑt hɪmsɛlf fɹaʊnɪŋ. nɑɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪz pɑɹɾ ʌv ɪt. ɪt kæn bi ɛvɹibɑɾi.

Mat's eyes narrowed, and Rand caught himself frowning. Not everyone is part of it. It can't be everybody.

"θæŋk ju," hi sɛd, "bʌɾ ɪm ɔl ɹaɪt. ɹɪli. haʊ fɑɹ tə ðə nɛks vɪlədʒ?"

"Thank you," he said, "but I'm all right. Really. How far to the next village?"

"kɛɹisfɝd? jə kən ɹitʃ ɪt bɪfɔɹ dɑɹk, wɔkɪŋ." mæstɝ kɪntʃ tʊk ɪz paɪp fɹəm bɪtwin ɪz tiθ ən pɝst ɪz lɪps θɔtfəli bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn. "fɝst ɔf, aɪ ɹɛkən jə fəɹ ɹʌnəweɪ 'pɹɛntəsəz, bʌt naʊ aɪ ɪkspɛkt ɪts sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ sɪɹiəs jəɹ ɹʌnɪŋ fɹʌm. doʊnt noʊ wʌt. doʊn kɛɹ. ɪm ə ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf dʒʌdʒ tə seɪ jəɹ nɑt dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ən nɑt laɪkli tə ɹɑb əɹ hɝɾ ɛnibəɾi. nɑt laɪk səm ɑn ðə ɹoʊd ðiz deɪz. aɪ ɡɑɾ ɪn tʃɹʌbəl ə taɪm əɹ tu maɪsɛlf wən aɪ wɑz jəɹ eɪdʒ. jə niɾ ə pleɪs tə kip aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ə fju deɪz, maɪ fɑɹm ɪz faɪv maɪlz ðət weɪ" - hi dʒɝkt ɪz hɛd təwɔɹd ðə kɑɹt tʃɹæk - "æn doʊnt noʊbɑdi ɛvɝ kʌm aʊt ðɛɹ. wʌtɛvɝz tʃeɪsɪŋ ju, woʊn laɪkli faɪn jə ðɛɹ." hi klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ əz ɪf ɪmbɛɹəs baɪ spikɪŋ soʊ mɛni wɝdz təɡɛðɝ.

"Carysford? You can reach it before dark, walking." Master Kinch took his pipe from between his teeth and pursed his lips thoughtfully before going on. "First off, I reckoned you for runaway 'prentices, but now I expect it's something more serious you're running from. Don't know what. Don't care. I'm a good enough judge to say you're not Darkfriends, and not likely to rob or hurt anybody. Not like some on the road these days. I got in trouble a time or two myself when I was your age. You need a place to keep out of sight a few days, my farm is five miles that way" - he jerked his head toward the cart track - "and don't nobody ever come out there. Whatever's chasing you, won't likely find you there." He cleared his throat as if embarrassed by speaking so many words together.

"haʊ wəd jə noʊ wʌt dɑɹkfɹɛnz lʊk laɪk?" mæt dɪmændəd. hi bækt əweɪ fɹəm ðə kɑɹt, ən ɪz hænd wɛn ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt. "wʌt dʒju noʊ əbaʊt dɑɹkfɹɛnz?"

"How would you know what Darkfriends look like?" Mat demanded. He backed away from the cart, and his hand went under his coat. "What do you know about Darkfriends?"

mæstɝ kɪntʃəz feɪs taɪɾənd. "sut jʊɹsɛlvz," hi sɛd, ən klʌk tə hɪz hɔɹs. ðə kɑɹt ɹoʊld ɔf daʊn ðə nɛɹoʊ pæθ, ən i nɛvɝ lʊk bæk.

Master Kinch's face tightened. "Suit yourselves," he said, and clucked to his horse. The cart rolled off down the narrow path, and he never looked back.

mæt lʊkt ət ɹænd, ən ɪz skaʊl feɪɾəd. "sɑɹi, ɹænd. jə niɾ ə pleɪs tə ɹɛst. meɪbi ɪf wi ɡoʊ æftɝ hɪm. . . ." hi ʃɹʌɡd. "aɪ dʒʌs kænt ɡɛɾ oʊvɝ ðə filɪŋ ðəɾ ɛvɹibɑɾiz æftɝ ʌs. laɪt, aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu waɪ ðeɪ wɝ. aɪ wɪʃ ɪt wɑz oʊvɝ. aɪ wɪʃ. . . ." hi tʃɹeɪld ɔf mɪzɝəbli.

Mat looked at Rand, and his scowl faded. "Sorry, Rand. You need a place to rest. Maybe if we go after him. . . ." He shrugged. "I just can't get over the feeling that everybody's after us. Light, I wish I knew why they were. I wish it was over. I wish. . . ." He trailed off miserably.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ stɪl səm ɡʊd pipəl," ɹænd sɛd. mæt stɑɹɾəd təwɔɹd ðə kɑɹt pæθ, dʒɔ klɛntʃt əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ðə læs θɪŋ i wɑntəd tə du, bʌt ɹænd stɑp hɪm. "wi kæn əfɔɹd tə stɑp dʒʌs tə ɹɛst, mæt. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðəɹ ɪz ɛniwɛɹ tə haɪd."

"There are still some good people," Rand said. Mat started toward the cart path, jaw clenched as if it were the last thing he wanted to do, but Rand stopped him. "We can't afford to stop just to rest, Mat. Besides, I don't think there is anywhere to hide."

mæt nɑɾəd, hɪz ɹɪlif ɛvəɾənt. hi tʃɹaɪd tə teɪk səm ə ɹændz bɝɾənz, ðə sæɾəlbæɡz ən tɑmz kloʊk ɹæpt ɝaʊn ðə keɪs hɑɹp, bʌt ɹænd hɛld ɑntu ðɛm. hɪz lɛɡz ɹɪli dɪd fil stʃɹɔŋɝ. wʌɾ ɛvɝz tʃeɪsɪŋ ʌs? hi θɔɾ əz ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd ɔf daʊn ðə ɹoʊd. nɑt tʃeɪsɪŋ. weɪɾɪŋ.

Mat nodded, his relief evident. He tried to take some of Rand's burdens, the saddlebags and Thom's cloak wrapped around the cased harp, but Rand held onto them. His legs really did feel stronger. What ever's chasing us? he thought as they started off down the road. Not chasing. Waiting.

ðə ɹeɪn hæd kəntɪnjud θɹu ðə naɪt ðeɪ stæɡɝɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðə dænsɪŋ kɑɹtmən, hæmɝɪŋ əɾ əm əz hɑɹɾ əz ðə θʌndɝ aʊɾ ʌv ə blæk skaɪ splɪt baɪ laɪtnɪŋ. ðɛɹ kloʊðz bɪkeɪm sɑɾən ɪn mɪnəts; ɪn ən aʊɝ ɹændz skɪn fɛl sɑɾən, tu, bʌt ðeɪ hæd lɛft fɔɹ kɪŋz bɪhaɪn ðɛm. mæt wɑz ɔl bʌt blaɪn ɪn ðə dɑɹk, skwɪntɪŋ peɪnfəli ət ðə ʃɑɹp flæʃɪz ðət meɪd tʃɹiz stæn aʊt stɑɹkli fəɹ ən ɪnstənt. ɹænd lɛɾ ɪm baɪ ðə hænd, bʌt mæt stɪl fɛlt aʊɾ itʃ stɛp ənsɝteɪnli. wɝi kɹist ɹændz fɔɹhɛd. ɪf mæt dɪd nɑt ɹɪɡeɪn ɪz saɪt, ðeɪ wəd bi sloʊd tə ə kɹɔl. ðeɪ wəd nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ əweɪ.

The rain had continued through the night they staggered away from The Dancing Cartman, hammering at them as hard as the thunder out of a black sky split by lightning. Their clothes became sodden in minutes; in an hour Rand's skin felt sodden, too, but they had left Four Kings behind them. Mat was all but blind in the dark, squinting painfully at the sharp flashes that made trees stand out starkly for an instant. Rand led him by the hand, but Mat still felt out each step uncertainly. Worry creased Rand's forehead. If Mat did not regain his sight, they would be slowed to a crawl. They would never get away.

mæt sim tə sɛns ɪz θɔt. dɪspaɪt ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk, ðə ɹeɪn hæd plæstɝd mæts hɛɹ əkɹɔs ɪz feɪs. "ɹænd," hi sɛd, "ju woʊn liv mi, wɪl ju? ɪf aɪ kæn kip ʌp?" hɪz vɔɪs kweɪvɝd.

Mat seemed to sense his thought. Despite the hood of his cloak, the rain had plastered Mat's hair across his face. "Rand," he said, "you won't leave me, will you? If I can't keep up?" His voice quavered.

"aɪ woʊn liv ju." ɹænd taɪɾənd ɪz ɡɹɪp ɑn ɪz fɹɛnz hænd. "aɪ woʊn liv jə noʊ mæɾɝ wʌt." laɪt hɛlp ʌs! θʌndɝ kɹæʃt oʊvɝhɛd, ən mæt stʌmbəld, ɔlmoʊs fɔlɪŋ, ɔlmoʊs pʊlɪŋ ɪm daʊn, tu. "wi hæv tə stɑp, mæt. ɪf wi kip ɡoʊɪŋ, jəl bɹeɪk ə lɛɡ."

"I won't leave you." Rand tightened his grip on his friend's hand. "I won't leave you no matter what." Light help us! Thunder crashed overhead, and Mat stumbled, almost falling, almost pulling him down, too. "We have to stop, Mat. If we keep going, you'll break a leg."

"ɡoʊd." laɪtnɪŋ splɪt ðə dɑɹk ɹaɪɾ əbʌv əm əz mæt spoʊk, ən ðə θʌndɝ kɹæk paʊndɪɾ ɛvɹi ʌðɝ saʊn ɪndə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, bʌɾ ɪn ðə flæʃ ɹænd kəd meɪk aʊt ðə neɪm ɑn mæts lɪps.

"Gode." Lightning split the dark right above them as Mat spoke, and the thunder crack pounded every other sound into the ground, but in the flash Rand could make out the name on Mat's lips.

"hiz dɛd." hiz tə bi. laɪt, lɛɾ ɪm bi dɛd.

"He's dead." He has to be. Light, let him be dead.

hi lɛd mæt tə səm bʊʃəz ðə laɪtnɪŋ flæʃ hæd ʃoʊd hɪm. ðeɪ hæd livz ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ə lɪɾəl ʃɛltɝ fɹəm ðə dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ɹeɪn. nɑɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ə ɡʊd tʃɹi maɪt, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɹɪsk ənʌðɝ laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹaɪk. ðeɪ maɪt nɑt bi soʊ lʌki, nɛks taɪm.

He led Mat to some bushes the lightning flash had showed him. They had leaves enough to give a little shelter from the driving rain. Not as much as a good tree might, but he did not want to risk another lightning strike. They might not be so lucky, next time.

hʌɾəld təɡɛðɝ bɪniθ ðə bʊʃəz, ðeɪ tʃɹaɪd tə ɝeɪnʒ ðɛɹ kloʊks tə meɪk ə lɪɾəl tɛn oʊvɝ ðə bɹæntʃəz. ɪt wɑz fɑɹ tu leɪt tə θɪŋk ə steɪɪŋ dʒɹaɪ, bʌt dʒʌst stɑpɪŋ ði ɪnsɛsən pɛltɪŋ ə ðə ɹeɪndʒɹɑps wəd bi sʌmθɪŋ. ðeɪ kɹaʊtʃt əɡɛnst itʃ ʌðɝ tə ʃɛɹ wʌt lɪɾəl bɑɾi wɔɹmθ wɑz lɛf tə ðɛm. dʒɹɪpɪŋ wɛɾ əz ðeɪ wɝ, ən mɔɹ dʒɹɪps kʌmɪŋ θɹu ðə kloʊks, ðeɪ ʃɪvɝd ðɛmsɛlvz ɪndə slip.

Huddled together beneath the bushes, they tried to arrange their cloaks to make a little tent over the branches. It was far too late to think of staying dry, but just stopping the incessant pelting of the raindrops would be something. They crouched against each other to share what little body warmth was left to them. Dripping wet as they were, and more drips coming through the cloaks, they shivered themselves into sleep.

ɹænd nu ɹaɪɾ əweɪ ɪt wɑz ə dʒɹim. hi wɑz bæk ɪn fɔɹ kɪŋz, bʌt ðə taʊn wɑz ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ hɪm. ðə wæɡənz wɝ ðɛɹ, bʌt noʊ pipəl, noʊ hɔɹsəz, noʊ dɑɡz. nʌθɪŋ əlaɪv. hi nu sʌmwʌn wɑz weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ hɪm, ðoʊ.

Rand knew right away it was a dream. He was back in Four Kings, but the town was empty except for him. The wagons were there, but no people, no horses, no dogs. Nothing alive. He knew someone was waiting for him, though.

əz i wɔk daʊn ðə ɹʌɾɪd stʃɹit, ðə bɪldɪŋz sim tə blɝ əz ðeɪ slɪd bɪhaɪn hɪm. wən i tɝn ɪz hɛd, ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ðɛɹ, sɑləd, bʌt ði ɪndɪstɪŋknəs ɹɪmeɪn ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɪz vɪʒən. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf oʊnli wʌɾ i sɔ ɹɪli ɪɡzɪstəd, ən ðən dʒʌst waɪl i wɑz siɪŋ. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪf i tɝn kwɪkli ɪnʌf i wəd si. . . . hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌt, bʌɾ ɪt meɪɾ ɪm ənizi, θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt.

As he walked down the rutted street, the buildings seemed to blur as they slid behind him. When he turned his head, they were all there, solid, but the indistinctness remained at the corners of his vision. It was as if only what he saw really existed, and then just while he was seeing. He was sure if he turned quickly enough he would see. . . . He was not sure what, but it made him uneasy, thinking about it.

ðə dænsɪŋ kɑɹtmən əpɪɹɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm. sʌmhaʊ ɪts ɡɛɹɪʃ peɪn simd ɡɹeɪ ən laɪfləs. hi wɛn ɪn. ɡoʊd wɑz ðɛɹ, əɾ ə teɪbəl.

The Dancing Cartman appeared in front of him. Somehow its garish paint seemed gray and lifeless. He went in. Gode was there, at a table.

hi oʊnli ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ðə mæn fɹəm ɪz kloʊðz, hɪz sɪlk ən dɑɹk vɛlvəts. ɡoʊdz skɪn wɑz ɹɛd, bɝn ən kɹækt ən uzɪŋ. hɪz feɪs wɑz ɔlmoʊst ə skʌl, hɪz lɪps ʃɹɪvəl tə bɛɹ tiθ ən ɡʌmz. əz ɡoʊd tɝn ɪz hɛd, səm ə hɪz hɛɹ kɹækt ɔf, paʊɾɝɪŋ tə sʊt wən ɪt hɪɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. hɪz lɪdləs aɪz stɛɹɾ ət ɹænd.

He only recognized the man from his clothes, his silk and dark velvets. Gode's skin was red, burned and cracked and oozing. His face was almost a skull, his lips shriveled to bare teeth and gums. As Gode turned his head, some of his hair cracked off, powdering to soot when it hit his shoulder. His lidless eyes stared at Rand.

"soʊ jə ɑɹ dɛd," ɹænd sɛd. hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz nɑɾ əfɹeɪd. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz noʊɪŋ ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə dʒɹim ðɪs taɪm.

"So you are dead," Rand said. He was surprised that he was not afraid. Perhaps it was knowing that it was a dream this time.

"jɛs," sɛd bælzəmənz vɔɪs, "bʌɾ i dɪd faɪn jə fəɹ mi. ðət dɪzɝvz səm ɹɪwɔɹd, doʊn jə θɪŋk?"

"Yes," said Ba'alzamon's voice, "but he did find you for me. That deserves some reward, don't you think?"

ɹænd tɝnd, ən dɪskʌvɝɾ i kəd bi əfɹeɪd, ivən noʊɪŋ ɪt wɑz ə dʒɹim. bælzəmənz kloʊðz wɝ ðə kʌlɝ ə dʒɹaɪd blʌd, ən ɹeɪdʒ ən heɪɾ ən tʃɹaɪəmf bæɾəld ɑn ɪz feɪs.

Rand turned, and discovered he could be afraid, even knowing it was a dream. Ba'alzamon's clothes were the color of dried blood, and rage and hate and triumph battled on his face.

"ju si, jʌŋɡəlɪŋ, jə kænɑt haɪd fɹəm mi fɝɛvɝ. wʌn weɪ əɹ ənʌðɝ aɪ faɪn ju. wʌt pɹətɛks jə ɔlsoʊ meɪks jə vʌlnɝəbəl. wʌn taɪm jə haɪd, ðə nɛks jə laɪɾ ə sɪɡnəl faɪɝ. kʌm tə mi, jʌŋɡəlɪŋ." hi hɛld aʊɾ ɪz hæn tə ɹænd. "ɪf maɪ haʊnz mʌs pʊl jə daʊn, ðeɪ meɪ nɑt bi dʒɛntəl. ðeɪ ɑɹ dʒɛləs ʌv wʌt jəl bi, wʌns juv nɛlt ət maɪ fit. ɪts jəɹ dɛstəni. jə bɪlɔŋ tə mi." ɡoʊdz bɝn tʌŋ meɪɾ ən æŋɡɹi, iɡɝ ɡɑɹbəl ə saʊnd.

"You see, youngling, you cannot hide from me forever. One way or another I find you. What protects you also makes you vulnerable. One time you hide, the next you light a signal fire. Come to me, youngling." He held out his hand to Rand. "If my hounds must pull you down, they may not be gentle. They are jealous of what you will be, once you have knelt at my feet. It is your destiny. You belong to me." Gode's burned tongue made an angry, eager garble of sound.

ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə wɛɾ ɪz lɪps, bʌɾ i hæd noʊ spɪɾ ɪn ɪz maʊð. "noʊ," hi mænədʒd, ən ðən ðə wɝdz keɪm mɔɹ izəli. "aɪ bɪlɔŋ tə maɪsɛlf. nɑt ju. nɑɾ ɛvɝ. maɪsɛlf. ɪf jəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz kɪl mi, jəl nɛvɝ əv mi."

Rand tried to wet his lips, but he had no spit in his mouth. "No," he managed, and then the words came more easily. "I belong to myself. Not you. Not ever. Myself. If your Darkfriends kill me, you'll never have me."

ðə faɪɝz ɪn bælzəmənz feɪs hiɾəd ðə ɹum tɪl ði ɛɹ swæm. "əlaɪv əɹ dɛd, jʌŋɡəlɪŋ, jə ɑɹ maɪn. ðə ɡɹeɪv bɪlɔŋz tə mi. iziɝ dɛd, bʌt bɛɾɝ əlaɪv. bɛɾɝ fəɹ ju, jʌŋɡəlɪŋ. ðə lɪvɪŋ əv mɔɹ paʊɝ ɪn moʊs θɪŋz." ɡoʊd meɪɾ ə ɡæbəlɪŋ saʊn əɡɛn. "jɛs, maɪ ɡʊd haʊnd. hɪɹ ɪz jəɹ ɹɪwɔɹd."

The fires in Ba'alzamon's face heated the room till the air swam. "Alive or dead, youngling, you are mine. The grave belongs to me. Easier dead, but better alive. Better for you, youngling. The living have more power in most things." Gode made a gabbling sound again. "Yes, my good hound. Here is your reward."

ɹænd lʊkt ət ɡoʊd dʒʌst ɪn taɪm tə si ðə mænz bɑɾi kɹʌmbəl tə dʌst. fəɹ ən ɪnstən ðə bɝn feɪs hɛld ə lʊk ə səblaɪm dʒɔɪ ðət tɝn tə hɔɹɝ ɪn ðə faɪnəl moʊmənt, əz ɪf i hæd sin sʌmθɪŋ weɪɾɪŋ i dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt. ɡoʊdz ɛmpti vɛlvət ɡɑɹməns sɛɾəld ɑn ðə tʃɛɹ ən ðə flɔɹ əmʌŋ ði æʃ.

Rand looked at Gode just in time to see the man's body crumble to dust. For an instant the burned face held a look of sublime joy that turned to horror in the final moment, as if he had seen something waiting he did not expect. Gode's empty velvet garments settled on the chair and the floor among the ash.

wən i tɝn bæk, bælzəmənz aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt hæn hæd bɪkʌm ə fɪst. "ju ɑɹ maɪn, jʌŋɡəlɪŋ, əlaɪv əɹ dɛd. ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld wɪl nɛvɝ sɝv ju. aɪ mɑɹk jə əz maɪn." hɪz fɪst oʊpənd, ən ə bɔl ə fleɪm ʃɑɾ aʊt. ɪt stʃɹʌk ɹænd ɪn ðə feɪs, ɪksploʊɾɪŋ, sɪɹɪŋ.

When he turned back, Ba'alzamon's outstretched hand had become a fist. "You are mine, youngling, alive or dead. The Eye of the World will never serve you. I mark you as mine." His fist opened, and a ball of flame shot out. It struck Rand in the face, exploding, searing.

ɹænd lɝtʃt əweɪk ɪn ðə dɑɹk, wɔɾɝ dʒɹɪpɪŋ θɹu ðə kloʊks ɑntu hɪz feɪs. hɪz hæn tʃɹɛmbəld əz i tʌtʃt ɪz tʃiks. ðə skɪn fɛl tɛndɝ, əz ɪf sʌnbɝnd.

Rand lurched awake in the dark, water dripping through the cloaks onto his face. His hand trembled as he touched his cheeks. The skin felt tender, as if sunburned.

sʌɾənli hi ɹilaɪz mæt wɑz twɪstɪŋ ən moʊnɪŋ ɪn ɪz slip. hi ʃʊk hɪm, ən mæt keɪm əweɪk wɪð ə wɪmpɝ.

Suddenly he realized Mat was twisting and moaning in his sleep. He shook him, and Mat came awake with a whimper.

"maɪ aɪz! oʊ, laɪt, maɪ aɪz! hi tʊk maɪ aɪz!"

"My eyes! Oh, Light, my eyes! He took my eyes!"

ɹænd hɛld ɪm kloʊs, kɹeɪɾəlɪŋ ɪm əɡɛnst ɪz tʃɛst əz ɪf i wɝ ə beɪbi. "jɔɹ ɔl ɹaɪt, mæt. jəɹ ɔl ɹaɪt. hi kæn hɝɾ ʌs. wi woʊn lɛt hɪm." hi kəd fil mæt ʃeɪkɪŋ, sɑbɪŋ ɪndə hɪz koʊt. "hi kæn hɝɾ ʌs," hi wɪspɝd, ən wɪʃt i bɪlivd ɪt. wʌt pɹətɛks jə meɪks jə vʌlnɝəbəl. aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ mæd.

Rand held him close, cradling him against his chest as if he were a baby. "You're all right, Mat. You're all right. He can't hurt us. We won't let him." He could feel Mat shaking, sobbing into his coat. "He can't hurt us," he whispered, and wished he believed it. What protects you makes you vulnerable. I am going mad.

dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ fɝs laɪt ðə daʊnpɔɹ dwɪndəld, ðə læs dʒɹɪzəl feɪɾɪŋ əz dɔn keɪm. ðə klaʊdz ɹɪmeɪnd, θɹɛɾənɪŋ əntɪl wɛl ɪndə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. ðə wɪn keɪm ʌp, ðɛn, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ðə klaʊdz ɔf tə ðə saʊθ, bɛɹɪŋ ə wɔɹmθləs sʌn ən slaɪsɪŋ θɹu ðɛɹ dʒɹɪpɪŋ wɛt kloʊðz. ðeɪ hæd nɑt slɛpt əɡɛn, bʌt ɡɹɑdʒəli ðeɪ dɑn ðɛɹ kloʊks ən sɛɾ ɔf istwɝd, ɹænd liɾɪŋ mæt baɪ ðə hænd. æftɝ ə waɪl mæt ivən fɛlt wɛl ɪnʌf tə kəmpleɪn əbaʊt wʌt ðə ɹeɪn hæd dʌn tə hɪz bɑstʃɹɪŋ. ɹænd wəd nɑt lɛɾ ɪm stɑp tə ɪkstʃeɪnʒ ɪt fəɹ ə dʒɹaɪ stʃɹɪŋ fɹəm ɪz pɑkət, ðoʊ; nɑt jɛt.

Just before first light the downpour dwindled, the last drizzle fading as dawn came. The clouds remained, threatening until well into the morning. The wind came up, then, driving the clouds off to the south, baring a warmthless sun and slicing through their dripping wet clothes. They had not slept again, but groggily they donned their cloaks and set off eastward, Rand leading Mat by the hand. After a while Mat even felt well enough to complain about what the rain had done to his bowstring. Rand would not let him stop to exchange it for a dry string from his pocket, though; not yet.

ðeɪ keɪm ɑn ənʌðɝ vɪlədʒ ʃɔɹtli æftɝ mɪddeɪ. ɹænd ʃɪvɝd hɑɹɾɝ ət ðə saɪɾ ə snʌɡ bɹɪk haʊsəz ən smoʊk ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm tʃɪmniz, bʌɾ i kɛp klɪɹ, liɾɪŋ mæt θɹu ðə wʊdz ən filz tə ðə saʊθ. ə loʊn fɑɹmɝ wɝkɪŋ wɪð ə speɪɾɪŋ fɔɹk ɪn ə mʌɾi fild wɑz ði oʊnli pɝsən i sɔ, ən i tʊk kɛɹ ðət ðə mæn dɪd nɑt si ðɛm, kɹaʊtʃɪŋ θɹu ðə tʃɹiz. ðə fɑɹmɝz ətɛnʃən wɑz ɔl ɑn ɪz wɝk, bʌt ɹænd kɛpt wʌn aɪ ɑn ɪm tɪl i wɑz lɔs tə saɪt. ɪf ɛni ʌv ɡoʊdz mɛn wɝ əlaɪv, pɝhæps ðeɪ wəd bɪliv i ən mæt hæd teɪkən ðə sʌðɝn ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə fɔɹ kɪŋz wən ðeɪ kəd nɑt faɪn ɛniwʌn u hæd sin əm ɪn ðɪs vɪlədʒ. ðeɪ keɪm bæk tə ðə ɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə saɪɾ ə ðə taʊn, ən wɔk ðɛɹ kloʊðz, ɪf nɑt dʒɹaɪ, ət lis tə dʒʌs dæmp.

They came on another village shortly after midday. Rand shivered harder at the sight of snug brick houses and smoke rising from chimneys, but he kept clear, leading Mat through the woods and fields to the south. A lone farmer working with a spading fork in a muddy field was the only person he saw, and he took care that the man did not see them, crouching through the trees. The farmer's attention was all on his work, but Rand kept one eye on him till he was lost to sight. If any of Gode's men were alive, perhaps they would believe he and Mat had taken the southern road out of Four Kings when they could not find anyone who had seen them in this village. They came back to the road out of sight of the town, and walked their clothes, if not dry, at least to just damp.

ən aʊɝ bɪɑn ðə taʊn ə fɑɹmɝ ɡeɪv əm ə ɹaɪɾ ɪn ɪz hæf-ɛmpti heɪweɪn. ɹænd hæd bɪn teɪkən baɪ sɝpɹaɪz waɪl lɔst ɪn wɝi əbaʊt mæt. mæt ʃildɪɾ ɪz aɪz fɹəm ðə sʌn wɪð ɪz hænd, wik əz ði æftɝnun laɪt wɑz, skwɪntɪŋ θɹu slɪɾɪd lɪdz ivən soʊ, ən i mʌɾɝd kəntɪnjuəli əbaʊt haʊ bɹaɪt ðə sʌn wɑz. wən ɹænd hɝd ðə ɹʌmbəl ə ðə heɪweɪn, ɪt wɑz tu leɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi. ðə sɑɾən ɹoʊd dɛɾənd saʊnd, ən ðə wæɡən wɪð ɪts tu-hɔɹs hɪtʃ wɑz oʊnli fɪfti jɑɹdz bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ðə dʒɹaɪvɝ ɔlɹɛɾi piɹɪŋ ət ðɛm.

An hour beyond the town a farmer gave them a ride in his half-empty haywain. Rand had been taken by surprise while lost in worry about Mat. Mat shielded his eyes from the sun with his hand, weak as the afternoon light was, squinting through slitted lids even so, and he muttered continually about how bright the sun was. When Rand heard the rumble of the haywain, it was too late already. The sodden road deadened sound, and the wagon with its two-horse hitch was only fifty yards behind them, the driver already peering at them.

tə ɹændz sɝpɹaɪz i dʒɹu ʌp ən ɔfɝɾ əm ə lɪft. ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz tu leɪt tə əvɔɪd biɪŋ sin, ən ɹəfjuzɪŋ ə ɹaɪd maɪt fɪks əm ɪn ðə mænz maɪnd. hi hɛlp mæt ʌp tə ðə sit bɪsaɪd ðə fɑɹmɝ, ðən klaɪmd ʌp bɪhaɪn hɪm.

To Rand's surprise he drew up and offered them a lift. Rand hesitated, but it was too late to avoid being seen, and refusing a ride might fix them in the man's mind. He helped Mat up to the seat beside the farmer, then climbed up behind him.

ælpɝt mʌl wɑz ə stɑləd mæn, wɪð ə skwɛɹ feɪs ən skwɛɹ hænz, boʊθ wɔɹn ən ɡɹuv fɹəm hɑɹd wɝk ən wɝi, ən i wɑntəd sʌmwʌn tə tɔk tə. hɪz kaʊz hæd ɡɔn dʒɹaɪ, hɪz tʃɪkənz hæd stɑp leɪɪŋ, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pæstʃɝ wɝθ ðə neɪm. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn mɛmɹi hi hæd hæd tə baɪ heɪ, ən hæf ə wæɡən wɑz ɔl "oʊl beɪn" wəd lɛɾ ɪm hæv. hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðəɹ wɑz ɛni tʃæns ʌv ɡɛɾɪŋ heɪ ɑn ɪz oʊn læn ðɪs jɪɹ, əɹ ɛni kaɪndə kɹɑp.

Alpert Mull was a stolid man, with a square face and square hands, both worn and grooved from hard work and worry, and he wanted someone to talk to. His cows had gone dry, his chickens had stopped laying, and there was no pasture worth the name. For the first time in memory he had had to buy hay, and half a wagon was all "old Bain" would let him have. He wondered whether there was any chance of getting hay on his own land this year, or any kind of crop.

"ðə kwin ʃəd də sʌmθɪŋ, ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin hɝ," hi mʌɾɝd, nʌklɪŋ ɪz fɔɹhɛd ɹɪspɛkfəli bʌɾ æbsəntmaɪndɪdli.

"The Queen should do something, the Light illumine her," he muttered, knuckling his forehead respectfully but absentmindedly.

hi hɑɹdli lʊkt ət ɹænd əɹ mæt, bʌt wən i lɛɾ əm daʊn baɪ ðə nɛɹoʊ, ɹeɪl-laɪn tʃɹæk ðət lɛɾ ɔf tə hɪz fɑɹm, hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən sɛd, ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf tə hɪmsɛlf, "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jəɹ ɹʌnɪŋ fɹʌm, ən aɪ doʊnt wɑn tə. aɪ hæv ə waɪf ən tʃɪlʒɹən. jə ʌndɝstænd? maɪ fæmli. ɪts hɑɹd taɪmz fəɹ hɛlpɪŋ stʃɹeɪnʒɝz."

He hardly looked at Rand or Mat, but when he let them down by the narrow, rail-lined track that led off to his farm, he hesitated, then said, almost as if to himself, "I don't know what you're running from, and I don't want to. I have a wife and children. You understand? My family. It's hard times for helping strangers."

mæt tʃɹaɪd tə stɪk ɪz hæn ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt, bʌt ɹænd hæɾ ɪz ɹɪst ən i hɛld ɑn. hi stʊɾ ɪn ðə ɹoʊd, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə mæn wɪθaʊt spikɪŋ.

Mat tried to stick his hand under his coat, but Rand had his wrist and he held on. He stood in the road, looking at the man without speaking.

"ɪf aɪ wɑz ə ɡʊd mæn," mʌl sɛd, "aɪɾ ɔfɝ ə kʌpəl ə lædz soʊk tə ðə skɪn ə pleɪs tə dʒɹaɪ aʊɾ ən ɡɛt wɔɹm ɪn fɹʌn ə maɪ faɪɝ. bʌɾ ɪts hɑɹd taɪmz, ən stʃɹeɪnʒɝz . . . . aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jəɹ ɹʌnɪŋ fɹʌm, ən aɪ doʊnt wɑn tə. jə ʌndɝstænd? maɪ fæmli." sʌɾənli hi pʊl tu lɔŋ, wʊlən skɑɹvz, dɑɹk ən θɪk, aʊɾ ə hɪz koʊt pɑkət. "ɪts nɑt mʌtʃ, bʌt hɪɹ. bɪlɔŋ tə maɪ bɔɪz. ðeɪv ʌðɝz. jə doʊnt noʊ mi, ʌndɝstænd? ɪts hɑɹd taɪmz."

"If I was a good man," Mull said, "I'd offer a couple of lads soaked to the skin a place to dry out and get warm in front of my fire. But it's hard times, and strangers . . . . I don't know what you're running from, and I don't want to. You understand? My family." Suddenly he pulled two long, woolen scarves, dark and thick, out of his coat pocket. "It's not much, but here. Belong to my boys. They have others. You don't know me, understand? It's hard times."

"wi nɛvɝ ivən sɔ ju," ɹænd əɡɹiɾ əz i tʊk ðə skɑɹvz. "ju ɑɹ ə ɡʊd mæn. ðə bɛst wiv mɛɾ ɪn deɪz."

"We never even saw you," Rand agreed as he took the scarves. "You are a good man. The best we've met in days."

ðə fɑɹmɝ lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd, ðən ɡɹeɪtfəl. ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz ɹeɪnz, hi tɝn ɪz hɔɹsəz daʊn ðə nɛɹoʊ leɪn. bɪfɔɹ i kəmpliɾəd ðə tɝn ɹænd wɑz liɾɪŋ mæt ɑn daʊn ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd.

The farmer looked surprised, then grateful. Gathering his reins, he turned his horses down the narrow lane. Before he completed the turn Rand was leading Mat on down the Caemlyn Road.

ðə wɪn stɪfən əz dʌsk kloʊzd ɪn. mæt bɪɡæn tə æsk kwɛɹələsli wən ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə stɑp, bʌt ɹænd kɛp muvɪŋ, pʊlɪŋ mæt bɪhaɪn hɪm, sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ mɔɹ ʃɛltɝ ðən ə spɑɾ ʌndɝ ə hɛdʒ. wɪð ðɛɹ kloʊðz stɪl klæmi ən ðə wɪnd ɡɛɾɪŋ koʊldɝ baɪ ðə mɪnət, hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ðeɪ kəd sɝvaɪv ənʌðɝ naɪɾ ɪn ði oʊpən. naɪt fɛl wɪθaʊɾ ɪm spɑɾɪŋ ɛniθɪŋ jusfəl. ðə wɪnd ɡɹu aɪsi, biɾɪŋ ɪz kloʊk. ðɛn, θɹu ðə dɑɹknəs əhɛd, hi sɔ laɪts. ə vɪlədʒ.

The wind stiffened as dusk closed in. Mat began to ask querulously when they were going to stop, but Rand kept moving, pulling Mat behind him, searching for more shelter than a spot under a hedge. With their clothes still clammy and the wind getting colder by the minute, he was not sure they could survive another night in the open. Night fell without him spotting anything useful. The wind grew icy, beating his cloak. Then, through the darkness ahead, he saw lights. A village.

hɪz hæn slɪɾ ɪndə hɪz pɑkət, filɪŋ ðə kɔɪnz ðɛɹ. mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf fəɹ ə mil ən ə ɹum fəɹ ðə tu ʌv ðɛm. ə ɹum aʊɾ ə ðə koʊl naɪt. ɪf ðeɪ steɪɾ ɪn ði oʊpən, ɪn ðə wɪn ən koʊld ɪn dæmp kloʊðz, ɛniwʌn u faʊn əm wəd laɪkli əz nɑt faɪn oʊnli tu kɔɹpsəz. ðeɪ dʒʌs hæd tə kip fɹəm ətʃɹæktɪŋ ɛni mɔɹ noʊɾəs ðən ðeɪ kəd hɛlp. noʊ pleɪɪŋ ðə flut, ən wɪð ɪz aɪz, mæt sɝɾənli kəd nɑt dʒʌɡəl. hi ɡɹæsp mæts hæn əɡɛn ən sɛɾ aʊt təwɔɹd ðə bɛkənɪŋ laɪts.

His hand slid into his pocket, feeling the coins there. More than enough for a meal and a room for the two of them. A room out of the cold night. If they stayed in the open, in the wind and cold in damp clothes, anyone who found them would likely as not find only two corpses. They just had to keep from attracting any more notice than they could help. No playing the flute, and with his eyes, Mat certainly could not juggle. He grasped Mat's hand again and set out toward the beckoning lights.

"wɛn ɑɹ wi ɡoʊɪŋ tə stɑp?" mæt æskt əɡɛn. ðə weɪ hi pɪɹɾ əhɛd, wɪð ɪz hɛd stʌk fɔɹwɝd, ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf mæt kəd si hɪm, mʌtʃ lɛs ðə vɪlədʒ laɪts.

"When are we going to stop?" Mat asked again. The way he peered ahead, with his head stuck forward, Rand was not sure if Mat could see him, much less the village lights.

"wɛn wɝ sʌmwɛɹ wɔɹm," hi ɹɪplaɪd.

"When we're somewhere warm," he replied.

pulz ə laɪt fɹəm haʊs wɪndoʊz lɪt ðə stʃɹits ə ðə taʊn, ən pipəl wɔkt əm ʌnkənsɝnd wɪð wʌt maɪt bi aʊɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk. ði oʊnli ɪn wɑz ə spɹɔlɪŋ bɪldɪŋ, ɔl ɑn wʌn flɔɹ, wɪð ðə lʊk ə hævɪŋ hæd ɹumz æɾəd ɪn bʌntʃəz oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz wɪθaʊɾ ɛni pɝtɪkjəlɝ plæn. ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ oʊpən tə lɛt sʌmwʌn aʊt, ən ə weɪv ə læftɝ ɹoʊld aʊɾ æftɝ hɪm.

Pools of light from house windows lit the streets of the town, and people walked them unconcerned with what might be out in the dark. The only inn was a sprawling building, all on one floor, with the look of having had rooms added in bunches over the years without any particular plan. The front door opened to let someone out, and a wave of laughter rolled out after him.

ɹænd fɹoʊz ɪn ðə stʃɹit, ðə dʒɹʌŋkən læftɝ ət ðə dænsɪŋ kɑɹtmən ɛkoʊɪŋ ɪn ɪz hɛd. hi wɑtʃt ðə mæn ɡoʊ daʊn ðə stʃɹit wɪð ə nʌn-tu-stɛɾi stʃɹaɪd, ðən tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən pʊʃt ðə dɔɹ oʊpən. hi tʊk kɛɹ ðəɾ ɪz kloʊk kʌvɝɾ ɪz sɔɹd. læftɝ swɛpt oʊvɝ hɪm.

Rand froze in the street, the drunken laughter at The Dancing Cartman echoing in his head. He watched the man go down the street with a none-too-steady stride, then took a deep breath and pushed the door open. He took care that his cloak covered his sword. Laughter swept over him.

læmps hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ðə haɪ silɪŋ meɪd ðə ɹum bɹaɪt, ən ɹaɪɾ əweɪ hi kəd si ən fil ðə dɪfɝəns fɹəm sæməl heɪks ɪn. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ dʒɹʌŋkənnəs hɪɹ, fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ. ðə ɹum wɑz fɪld wɪð pipəl u lʊk tə bi fɑɹmɝz ən taʊnsmɪn, ɪf nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli soʊbɝ, nɑt tu fɑɹ fɹəm ɪt. ðə læftɝ wɑz ɹil, ɪf ə bɪt fɔɹst ɝaʊn ði ɛdʒəz. pipəl læfɪŋ tə fɝɡɛt ðɛɹ tʃɹʌbəlz, bʌt wɪð tʃɹu mɝθ ɪn ɪt, tu. ðə kɑmən ɹum ɪtsɛlf wɑz niɾ ən klin, ən wɔɹm fɹəm ə faɪɝ ɹɔɹɪŋ ɪn ə bɪɡ faɪɝpleɪs ət ðə fɑɹ ɛnd. ðə sɝvɪŋ meɪdz' smaɪlz wɝ əz wɔɹm əz ðə faɪɝ, ən wən ðeɪ læft ɹænd kəd tɛl ɪt wɑz kəz ðeɪ wɑntəd tə.

Lamps hanging from the high ceiling made the room bright, and right away he could see and feel the difference from Saml Hake's inn. There was no drunkenness here, for one thing. The room was filled with people who looked to be farmers and townsmen, if not entirely sober, not too far from it. The laughter was real, if a bit forced around the edges. People laughing to forget their troubles, but with true mirth in it, too. The common room itself was neat and clean, and warm from a fire roaring in a big fireplace at the far end. The serving maids' smiles were as warm as the fire, and when they laughed Rand could tell it was because they wanted to.

ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz əz klin əz ɪz ɪn, wɪð ə ɡlimɪŋ waɪɾ eɪpɹən ɝaʊn ɪz bʌlk. ɹænd wɑz ɡlæd tə si hi wɑz ə staʊt mæn; hi daʊɾɪd ɪf i wəɾ ɛvɝ əɡɛn tʃɹʌst ə skɪni ɪnkipɝ. hɪz neɪm wɑz ɹulən ɔlwaɪn - ə ɡʊɾ oʊmən, ɹænd θɔt, wɪð soʊ mʌtʃ ə ðə saʊn ʌv ɛmənz fil tə ɪt - ən i aɪɾ əm ʌp ən daʊn, ðən pəlaɪtli mɛnʃən peɪɪŋ ɪn ədvæns.

The innkeeper was as clean as his inn, with a gleaming white apron around his bulk. Rand was glad to see he was a stout man; he doubted if he would ever again trust a skinny innkeeper. His name was Rulan Allwine - a good omen, Rand thought, with so much of the sound of Emond's Field to it - and he eyed them up and down, then politely mentioned paying in advance.

"nɑt sədʒɛstɪŋ jəɹ ðə sɔɹt, ʌndɝstænd, bʌt ðɛɹz səm ɑn ðə ɹoʊd ðiz deɪz ɑɹən tu pɝtɪkjəlɝ əbaʊt peɪɪŋ ʌp kʌm mɔɹnɪŋ. simz tə bi ə lɑɾ ə jʌŋ foʊks hɛɾəd fəɹ keɪɛmlɪn."

"Not suggesting you're the sort, understand, but there's some on the road these days aren't too particular about paying up come morning. Seems to be a lot of young folks headed for Caemlyn."

ɹænd wɑz nɑɾ əfɛndəd, nɑɾ əz dæmp ən bɪdʒɹæɡəld əz i wɑz. wən mæstɝ ɔlwaɪn mɛnʃən ðə pɹaɪs, ðoʊ, hɪz aɪz waɪɾənd, ən mæt meɪɾ ə saʊn əz ɪf i hæd tʃoʊkt ɑn sʌmθɪŋ.

Rand was not offended, not as damp and bedraggled as he was. When Master Allwine mentioned the price, though, his eyes widened, and Mat made a sound as if he had choked on something.

ði ɪnkipɝz dʒaʊlz swʌŋ əz i ʃʊk ɪz hɛd ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli, bʌɾ i sim tə bi juz tə ɪt. "taɪmz ɑɹ hɑɹd," hi sɛɾ ɪn ə ɹɪzaɪn vɔɪs. "ðɛɹ ɪzən mʌtʃ, ən wʌt ðəɹ ɪz kɑsts faɪv taɪmz wʌɾ ɪt juz tə. ɪɾəl bi mɔɹ nɛks mʌnθ, əl leɪ oʊθ ɑn ɪt."

The innkeeper's jowls swung as he shook his head regretfully, but he seemed to be used to it. "Times are hard," he said in a resigned voice. "There isn't much, and what there is costs five times what it used to. It'll be more next month, I'll lay oath on it."

ɹænd dʌɡ hɪz mʌni aʊɾ ən lʊkt ət mæt. mæts maʊθ taɪɾənd stʌbɝnli. "ju wɑnə slip ʌndɝ ə hɛdʒ?" ɹænd æskt. mæt saɪɾ ən ɹɪlʌktənli ɛmptiɾ ɪz pɑkət. wən ðə ɹɛkənɪŋ wɑz peɪd, ɹænd ɡɹɪməst ət ðə lɪɾəl ðət ɹɪmeɪn tə dɪvaɪd wɪð mæt.

Rand dug his money out and looked at Mat. Mat's mouth tightened stubbornly. "You want to sleep under a hedge?" Rand asked. Mat sighed and reluctantly emptied his pocket. When the reckoning was paid, Rand grimaced at the little that remained to divide with Mat.

bʌt tɛn mɪnəts leɪɾɝ ðeɪ wɝ iɾɪŋ stu əɾ ə teɪbəl ɪn ə kɔɹnɝ nɪɹ ðə faɪɝpleɪs, pʊʃɪŋ ɪɾ ɑntu ðɛɹ spunz wɪð tʃʌŋks ə bɹɛd. ðə pɔɹʃənz wɝ nɑɾ əz lɑɹdʒ əz ɹænd kəɾ əv wɪʃt, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ hɑt, ən fɪlɪŋ. wɔɹmθ fɹəm ðə hɑɹθ sipt ɪndə hɪm sloʊli. hi pɹitɛndəd tə kip ɪz aɪz ɑn ɪz pleɪt, bʌɾ i wɑtʃt ðə dɔɹ ɪntɛnli. ðoʊz u keɪm ɪn əɹ wɛn aʊɾ ɔl lʊk laɪk fɑɹmɝz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə kwaɪəɾ ɪz fɪɹ.

But ten minutes later they were eating stew at a table in a corner near the fireplace, pushing it onto their spoons with chunks of bread. The portions were not as large as Rand could have wished, but they were hot, and filling. Warmth from the hearth seeped into him slowly. He pretended to keep his eyes on his plate, but he watched the door intently. Those who came in or went out all looked like farmers, but it was not enough to quiet his fear.

mæt eɪt sloʊli, seɪvɝɪŋ itʃ baɪt, ðoʊ hi mʌɾɝd əbaʊt ðə laɪt fɹəm ðə læmps. æftɝ ə taɪm i dʌɡ aʊt ðə skɑɹf ælpɝt mʌl hæd ɡɪvən ɪm ən waʊn ɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz fɔɹhɛd, pʊlɪŋ ɪt daʊn əntɪl ɪz aɪz wɝ ɔlmoʊs hɪɾən. ðət ɡɑɾ əm səm lʊks ɹænd wɪʃt ðeɪ kəɾ əv əvɔɪɾəd. hi klin ɪz pleɪt hɝidli, ɝdʒɪŋ mæt tə də ðə seɪm, ðən æsk mæstɝ ɔlwaɪn fəɹ ðɛɹ ɹum.

Mat ate slowly, savoring each bite, though he muttered about the light from the lamps. After a time he dug out the scarf Alpert Mull had given him and wound it around his forehead, pulling it down until his eyes were almost hidden. That got them some looks Rand wished they could have avoided. He cleaned his plate hurriedly, urging Mat to do the same, then asked Master Allwine for their room.

ði ɪnkipɝ sim sɝpɹaɪz ðət ðeɪ wɝ ɹɪtaɪɹɪŋ soʊ ɝli, bʌɾ i meɪd noʊ kɑmɛnt. hi ɡɑɾ ə kændəl ən ʃoʊɾ əm θɹu ə dʒʌmbəl ə kɔɹɪɾɝz tə ə smɔl ɹum, wɪð tu nɛɹoʊ bɛdz, bæk ɪn ə fɑɹ kɔɹnɝ ə ði ɪn. wən i lɛft, ɹænd dʒɹɑpt ɪz bʌndəlz bɪsaɪɾ ɪz bɛd, tɔst ɪz kloʊk oʊvɝ ə tʃɛɹ, ən fɛl ɑn ðə kʌvɝlət fʊli dʒɹɛst. ɔl ə hɪz kloʊðz wɝ stɪl dæmp ən ənkʌmftəɹbəl, bʌɾ ɪf ðeɪ hæd tə ɹʌn, hi wɑntəd tə bi ɹɛɾi. hi lɛf ðə sɔɹd bɛlt ɑn, tu, ən slɛpt wɪð ɪz hæn ɑn ðə hɪlt.

The innkeeper seemed surprised that they were retiring so early, but he made no comment. He got a candle and showed them through a jumble of corridors to a small room, with two narrow beds, back in a far corner of the inn. When he left, Rand dropped his bundles beside his bed, tossed his cloak over a chair, and fell on the coverlet fully dressed. All of his clothes were still damp and uncomfortable, but if they had to run, he wanted to be ready. He left the sword belt on, too, and slept with his hand on the hilt.

ə ɹustɝ kɹoʊɪŋ dʒɝkt ɪm əweɪk ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ. hi leɪ ðɛɹ, wɑtʃɪŋ dɔn laɪɾən ðə wɪndoʊ, ən wʌndɝɾ ɪf i dɛɹd slip ə lɪɾəl lɔŋɡɝ. slip dʊɹɪŋ deɪlaɪt, wən ðeɪ kəd bi muvɪŋ. ə jɔn meɪɾ ɪz dʒɔz kɹæk.

A rooster crowing jerked him awake in the morning. He lay there, watching dawn lighten the window, and wondered if he dared sleep a little longer. Sleep during daylight, when they could be moving. A yawn made his jaws crack.

"heɪ," mæt ɪkskleɪmd, "aɪ kən si!" hi sæɾ ʌp ɑn ɪz bɛd, skwɪntɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə ɹum. "sʌm, ɛniweɪ. jəɹ feɪs ɪz stɪl ə lɪɾəl blɝi, bʌɾ aɪ kən tɛl u jə ɑɹ. aɪ nu aɪd bi ɔl ɹaɪt. baɪ tənaɪɾ əl si bɛɾɝ ðən jə du. əɡɛn."

"Hey," Mat exclaimed, "I can see!" He sat up on his bed, squinting around the room. "Some, anyway. Your face is still a little blurry, but I can tell who you are. I knew I'd be all right. By tonight I'll see better than you do. Again."

ɹænd spɹæŋ aʊɾ ə bɛd, skɹætʃɪŋ əz i skupt ʌp ɪz kloʊk. hɪz kloʊðz wɝ ɹɪŋkəl fɹəm dʒɹaɪɪŋ ɑn ɪm waɪl i slɛpt, ən ðeɪ ɪtʃt. "wɝ weɪstɪŋ deɪlaɪt," hi sɛd. mæt skɹæmbəld ʌp əz fæst əz i hæd; hi wɑz skɹætʃɪŋ, tu.

Rand sprang out of bed, scratching as he scooped up his cloak. His clothes were wrinkled from drying on him while he slept, and they itched. "We're wasting daylight," he said. Mat scrambled up as fast as he had; he was scratching, too.

ɹænd dɪd fil ɡʊd. ðeɪ wɝ ə deɪ əweɪ fɹəm fɔɹ kɪŋz, ən nʌn ʌv ɡoʊdz mɛn hæd ʃoʊɾ ʌp. ə deɪ kloʊsɝ tə keɪɛmlɪn, wɛɹ mɔɪɹeɪn wəd bi weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðɛm. ʃi wʊd. noʊ mɔɹ wɝiɪŋ əbaʊt dɑɹkfɹɛnz wʌns ðeɪ wɝ bæk wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ. ɪt wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ tə bi lʊkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd soʊ mʌtʃ tə biɪŋ wɪð ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. laɪt, wən aɪ si mɔɪɹeɪn əɡɛn, əl kɪs hɝ! hi læft ət ðə θɔt. hi fɛlt ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf tə ɪnvɛst səm ə ðɛɹ dwɪndəlɪŋ stɑk ə kɔɪnz ɪn bɹɛkfəst - ə bɪɡ loʊf ə bɹɛɾ ən ə pɪtʃɝ ə mɪlk, koʊl fɹəm ðə spɹɪŋ haʊs.

Rand did feel good. They were a day away from Four Kings, and none of Gode's men had showed up. A day closer to Caemlyn, where Moiraine would be waiting for them. She would. No more worrying about Darkfriends once they were back with the Aes Sedai and the Warder. It was strange to be looking forward so much to being with an Aes Sedai. Light, when I see Moiraine again, I'll kiss her! He laughed at the thought. He felt good enough to invest some of their dwindling stock of coins in breakfast - a big loaf of bread and a pitcher of milk, cold from the spring house.

ðeɪ wɝ iɾɪŋ ɪn ðə bæk ə ðə kɑmən ɹum wən ə jʌŋ mæn keɪm ɪn, ə vɪlədʒ juθ baɪ ðə lʊk ə hɪm, wɪð ə kɑki spɹɪŋ tə hɪz wɔk ən twɝlɪŋ ə klɔθ kæp, wɪð ə fɛðɝ ɪn ɪt, ɑn wʌn fɪŋɡɝ. ði oʊnli ʌðɝ pɝsən ɪn ðə ɹum wɑz ən oʊl mæn swipɪŋ aʊt; hi nɛvɝ lʊkt ʌp fɹəm ɪz bɹum. ðə jʌŋ mænz aɪz swɛp dʒɔntəli ɝaʊn ðə ɹum, bʌt wən ðeɪ lɪɾ ɑn ɹænd ən mæt, ðə kæp fɛl ɔf ɪz fɪŋɡɝ. hi stɛɹɾ əɾ əm fəɹ ə fʊl mɪnət bɪfɔɹ snætʃɪŋ ðə kæp fɹəm ðə flɔɹ, ðən stɛɹd səm mɔɹ, ɹʌnɪŋ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɪz θɪk hɛɾ ə dɑɹk kɝlz. faɪnəli hi keɪm oʊvɝ tə ðɛɹ teɪbəl, hɪz fit dʒɹæɡɪŋ.

They were eating in the back of the common room when a young man came in, a village youth by the look of him, with a cocky spring to his walk and twirling a cloth cap, with a feather in it, on one finger. The only other person in the room was an old man sweeping out; he never looked up from his broom. The young man's eyes swept jauntily around the room, but when they lit on Rand and Mat, the cap fell off his finger. He stared at them for a full minute before snatching the cap from the floor, then stared some more, running his fingers through his thick head of dark curls. Finally he came over to their table, his feet dragging.

hi wɑz oʊldɝ ðən ɹænd, bʌɾ i stʊd lʊkɪŋ daʊn əɾ əm dɪfəɾəntli. "maɪn ɪf aɪ sɪt daʊn?" hi æskt, ən ɪmiɾiətli swɑloʊd hɑɹɾ əz ɪf i maɪɾ əv sɛd ðə ɹɔŋ θɪŋ.

He was older than Rand, but he stood looking down at them diffidently. "Mind if I sit down?" he asked, and immediately swallowed hard as if he might have said the wrong thing.

ɹænd θɔɾ i maɪt bi hoʊpɪŋ tə ʃɛɹ ðɛɹ bɹɛkfəst, ðoʊ hi lʊkt eɪbəl tə baɪ hɪz oʊn. hɪz blu-stʃɹaɪpt ʃɝt wɑz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɝaʊn ðə kɑlɝ, ən ɪz dɑɹk blu kloʊk ɔl ɝaʊn ðə hɛm. hɪz lɛðɝ buts hæd nɛvɝ bɪn nɪɹ ɛni wɝk ðət skʌf ðɛm, ðət ɹænd kəd si. hi nɑɾəd tə ə tʃɛɹ.

Rand thought he might be hoping to share their breakfast, though he looked able to buy his own. His blue-striped shirt was embroidered around the collar, and his dark blue cloak all around the hem. His leather boots had never been near any work that scuffed them, that Rand could see. He nodded to a chair.

mæt stɛɹɾ ət ðə fɛloʊ əz i dʒɹu ðə tʃɛɹ tə ðə teɪbəl. ɹænd kəd nɑt tɛl ɪf i wɑz ɡlɛɹɪŋ əɹ dʒʌs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə si klɪɹli. ɪn ɛni keɪs, mæts fɹaʊn hæɾ ən ɪfɛkt. ðə jʌŋ mæn fɹoʊz hæfweɪ tə sɪɾɪŋ, ən dɪd nɑt loʊɝ hɪmsɛlf ɔl ðə weɪ əntɪl ɹænd nɑɾəd əɡɛn.

Mat stared at the fellow as he drew the chair to the table. Rand could not tell if he was glaring or just trying to see clearly. In any case, Mat's frown had an effect. The young man froze halfway to sitting, and did not lower himself all the way until Rand nodded again.

"wʌts jəɹ neɪm?" ɹænd æskt.

"What's your name?" Rand asked.

"maɪ neɪm? maɪ neɪm. ɑ . . . kɔl mi peɪtʃɹ." hɪz aɪz ʃɪftəd nɝvəsli. "ɑ . . . ðɪs ɪz nɑt maɪ aɪdiə, jə ʌndɝstænd. aɪ hæv tə də ɪt. aɪ dɪdnt wɑn tə, bʌt ðeɪ meɪd mi. juv tə ʌndɝstæn ðæt. aɪ doʊnt - "

"My name? My name. Ah . . . call me Paitr." His eyes shifted nervously. "Ah . . . this is not my idea, you understand. I have to do it. I didn't want to, but they made me. You have to understand that. I don't - "

ɹænd wɑz bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə tɛns wən mæt ɡɹaʊld, "dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

Rand was beginning to tense when Mat growled, "Darkfriend."

peɪtʃɹ ɡeɪv ə dʒɝk ən hæf lɪftəɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz tʃɛɹ, stɛɹɪŋ waɪldli ɝaʊn ðə ɹum əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ fɪfti pipəl tə oʊvɝhɪɹ. ði oʊl mænz hɛd wɑz stɪl bɛn oʊvɝ ðə bɹum, hɪz ətɛnʃən ɑn ðə flɔɹ. peɪtʃɹ sæt bæk daʊn ən lʊk fɹəm ɹænd tə mæt ən bæk ənsɝteɪnli. swɛt biɾɪd ɑn ɪz ʌpɝ lɪp. ɪt wɑz ækjəzeɪʃən ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɛniwʌn swɛt, bʌɾ i sɛd nɑɾ ə wɝɾ əɡɛnst ɪt.

Paitr gave a jerk and half lifted out of his chair, staring wildly around the room as if there were fifty people to overhear. The old man's head was still bent over the broom, his attention on the floor. Paitr sat back down and looked from Rand to Mat and back uncertainly. Sweat beaded on his upper lip. It was accusation enough to make anyone sweat, but he said not a word against it.

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sloʊli. æftɝ ɡoʊd, hi nu ðət dɑɹkfɹɛnz dɪd nɑt nɛsəsɛɹəli hæv ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ ɑn ðɛɹ fɔɹhɛdz, bʌɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ɪz kloʊðz ðɪs peɪtʃɹ cʊɾə fɪt ɹaɪɾ ɪn ɛmənz fild. nʌθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪm hɪntəɾ ət mɝɾɝ ən wɝs. noʊbɑdi wʊɾə ɹɪmɑɹkt ɪm twaɪs. ət list ɡoʊd hæd bɪn . . . dɪfɹənt.

Rand shook his head slowly. After Gode, he knew that Darkfriends did not necessarily have the Dragon's Fang on their foreheads, but except for his clothes this Paitr could have fit right in Emond's Field. Nothing about him hinted at murder and worse. Nobody would have remarked him twice. At least Gode had been . . . different.

"liv əs əloʊn," ɹænd sɛd. "æn tɛl jəɹ fɹɛnz tə liv əs əloʊn. wi wɑnt nʌθɪŋ fɹəm ðɛm, ən ðəl ɡɛt nʌθɪŋ fɹəm ʌs."

"Leave us alone," Rand said. "And tell your friends to leave us alone. We want nothing from them, and they'll get nothing from us."

"ɪf jə doʊnt," mæt æɾəd fɪɹsli, "aɪl neɪm jə fəɹ wʌt jə ɑɹ. si wʌt jəɹ vɪlədʒ fɹɛnz θɪŋk ə ðæt."

"If you don't," Mat added fiercely, "I'll name you for what you are. See what your village friends think of that."

ɹænd hoʊpt i dɪd nɑt ɹɪli min ɪt. ðət kəd kɑz əz mʌtʃ tʃɹʌbəl fəɹ ðə tu ʌv əm əz ɪt dɪd fəɹ peɪtʃɹ.

Rand hoped he did not really mean it. That could cause as much trouble for the two of them as it did for Paitr.

peɪtʃɹ sim tə teɪk ðə θɹɛt sɪɹiəsli. hɪz feɪs ɡɹu peɪl. "aɪ . . . aɪ hɝd wʌt hæpən ət fɔɹ kɪŋz. səm ʌv ɪt, ɛniweɪ. wɝd tʃɹævəlz. wɪv weɪz ə hɪɹɪŋ θɪŋz. bʌt ðɛɹz noʊbɑdi hɪɹ tə tʃɹæp ju. aɪm əloʊn, ən . . . ən aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə tɔk."

Paitr seemed to take the threat seriously. His face grew pale. "I . . . I heard what happened at Four Kings. Some of it, anyway. Word travels. We have ways of hearing things. But there's nobody here to trap you. I'm alone, and . . . and I just want to talk."

"əbaʊt wʌt?" mæt æskt ət ðə seɪm taɪm ðət ɹænd sɛd, "wɝ nɑɾ ɪntʃɹəstəd." ðeɪ lʊkt əɾ itʃ ʌðɝ, ən mæt ʃɹʌɡd. "wɝ nɑɾ ɪntʃɹəstəd," hi sɛd.

"About what?" Mat asked at the same time that Rand said, "We're not interested." They looked at each other, and Mat shrugged. "We're not interested," he said.

ɹænd ɡʌlp ðə læst ə ðə mɪlk ən stʌf ðə hil ə hɪz hæf ə ðə bɹɛɾ ɪndə hɪz pɑkət. wɪð ðɛɹ mʌni ɔlmoʊst ɡɔn, ɪt maɪt bi ðɛɹ nɛks mil.

Rand gulped the last of the milk and stuffed the heel of his half of the bread into his pocket. With their money almost gone, it might be their next meal.

haʊ tə liv ði ɪn? ɪf peɪtʃɹ dɪskʌvɝd ðət mæt wɑz ɔlmoʊs blaɪnd, hi wəd tɛl ʌðɝz . . . ʌðɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. wʌns ɹænd hæd sin ə wʊlf sɛpɝeɪɾ ə kɹɪpəld ʃip fɹəm ðə flɑk; ðəɹ wɝ ʌðɝ wʊlvz ɝaʊnd, ən i kəd niðɝ liv ðə flɑk nɔɹ ɡɛɾ ə klɪɹ ʃɑt wɪð ɪz baʊ. əz sun əz ðə ʃip wɑz əloʊn, bliɾɪŋ wɪð tɛɹɝ, hɑbəlɪŋ fɹæntəkəli ɑn θɹi lɛɡz, ðə wʌn wʊlf tʃeɪsɪŋ ɪt bɪkeɪm tɛn əz ɪf baɪ mædʒɪk. ðə mɛmɹi ʌv ɪt tɝn ɪz stʌmək. ðeɪ kəd nɑt steɪ ðɛɹ, iðɝ. ivən ɪf peɪtʃɹ wɑz tɛlɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ əbaʊt biɪŋ əloʊn, haʊ lɔŋ wəɾ i steɪ ðət weɪ?

How to leave the inn? If Paitr discovered that Mat was almost blind, he would tell others . . . other Darkfriends. Once Rand had seen a wolf separate a crippled sheep from the flock; there were other wolves around, and he could neither leave the flock nor get a clear shot with his bow. As soon as the sheep was alone, bleating with terror, hobbling frantically on three legs, the one wolf chasing it became ten as if by magic. The memory of it turned his stomach. They could not stay there, either. Even if Paitr was telling the truth about being alone, how long would he stay that way?

"taɪm tə ɡoʊ, mæt," hi sɛd, ən hɛld ɪz bɹɛθ. əz mæt stɑɹɾəd tə stænd, hi pʊl peɪtʃɹz aɪz tə hɪmsɛlf baɪ linɪŋ fɔɹwɝɾ ən seɪɪŋ, "liv əs əloʊn, dɑɹkfɹɛnd. aɪ woʊn tɛl jə əɡɛn. liv - əs - əloʊn."

"Time to go, Mat," he said, and held his breath. As Mat started to stand, he pulled Paitr's eyes to himself by leaning forward and saying, "Leave us alone, Darkfriend. I won't tell you again. Leave - us - alone."

peɪtʃɹ swɑloʊd hɑɹɾ ən pɹɛs bæk ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ; ðəɹ wɑz noʊ blʌd lɛft ɪn ɪz feɪs əɾ ɔl. ɪt meɪd ɹænd θɪŋk ʌv ə mɹdʒɹɑl.

Paitr swallowed hard and pressed back in his chair; there was no blood left in his face at all. It made Rand think of a Myrddraal.

baɪ ðə taɪm i lʊk bæk ət mæt, mæt wɑz ɑn ɪz fit, hɪz ɔkwɝdnəs ənsin. ɹænd heɪstəli hʌŋ ɪz oʊn sæɾəlbæɡz ən ʌðɝ bʌndəlz ɝaʊn hɪm, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ɪz kloʊk oʊvɝ ðə sɔɹɾ əz i dɪd. meɪbi peɪtʃɹ ɔlɹɛɾi nu əbaʊɾ ɪt; meɪbi ɡoʊd hæd toʊl bælzəmən, ən bælzəmən hæd toʊl peɪtʃɹ; bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk soʊ. hi θɔt peɪtʃɹ hæɾ oʊnli ðə veɪɡɪst aɪdiə ʌv wʌt hæd hæpən ɪn fɔɹ kɪŋz. ðət wɑz waɪ hi wɑz soʊ fɹaɪɾənd.

By the time he looked back at Mat, Mat was on his feet, his awkwardness unseen. Rand hastily hung his own saddlebags and other bundles around him, trying to keep his cloak over the sword as he did. Maybe Paitr already knew about it; maybe Gode had told Ba'alzamon, and Ba'alzamon had told Paitr; but he did not think so. He thought Paitr had only the vaguest idea of what had happened in Four Kings. That was why he was so frightened.

ðə kəmpɛɹəɾɪvli bɹaɪɾ aʊtlaɪn ə ðə dɔɹ hɛlp mæt meɪk ə bilaɪn fəɹ ɪt, ɪf nɑt kwɪkli, ðən nɑt sloʊ ɪnʌf tə sim ənnætʃɹəl, iðɝ. ɹænd fɑloʊd kloʊsli, pɹeɪɪŋ fəɹ ɪm nɑt tə stʌmbəl. hi wɑz θæŋkfəl mæt hæɾ ə klɪɹ, stʃɹeɪt pæθ, wɪð noʊ teɪbəlz əɹ tʃɛɹz ɪn ðə weɪ.

The comparatively bright outline of the door helped Mat make a beeline for it, if not quickly, then not slow enough to seem unnatural, either. Rand followed closely, praying for him not to stumble. He was thankful Mat had a clear, straight path, with no tables or chairs in the way.

bɪhaɪn ɪm peɪtʃɹ sʌɾənli lɛp tə hɪz fit. "weɪt," hi sɛd dɛspɝətli. "ju hæv tə weɪt."

Behind him Paitr suddenly leaped to his feet. "Wait," he said desperately. "You have to wait."

"liv əs əloʊn," ɹænd sɛd wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ bæk. ðeɪ wɝ ɔlmoʊs tə ðə dɔɹ, ən mæt hæd nɑt pʊɾ ə fʊt ɹɔŋ jɛt.

"Leave us alone," Rand said without looking back. They were almost to the door, and Mat had not put a foot wrong yet.

"dʒʌs lɪsən tə mi," peɪtʃɹ sɛd, ən pʊɾ ɪz hæn ɑn ɹændz ʃoʊldɝ tə stɑp hɪm.

"Just listen to me," Paitr said, and put his hand on Rand's shoulder to stop him.

ɪmədʒəz spʌn ɪn ɪz hɛd. ðə tʃɹɑlɑk, nɑɹɡ, lipɪŋ əɾ ɪm ɪn ɪz oʊn hoʊm. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl θɹɛɾənɪŋ ət ðə stæɡ ən laɪən ɪn bɛɹlən. hæfmən ɛvɹiwɛɹ, feɪdz tʃeɪsɪŋ əm tə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, kʌmɪŋ fəɹ əm ɪn waɪtbɹɪdʒ. dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɛvɹiwɛɹ. hi wɝld, hɪz hæn bɔlɪŋ ʌp. "aɪ sɛd, liv əs əloʊn!" hɪz fɪs tʊk peɪtʃɹ flʌʃ ɑn ðə noʊz.

Images spun in his head. The Trolloc, Narg, leaping at him in his own home. The Myrddraal threatening at the Stag and Lion in Baerlon. Halfmen everywhere, Fades chasing them to Shadar Logoth, coming for them in Whitebridge. Darkfriends everywhere. He whirled, his hand balling up. "I said, leave us alone!" His fist took Paitr flush on the nose.

ðə dɑɹkfɹɛn fɛl ɑn ɪz bɑɾəm ən sæt ðəɹ ɑn ðə flɔɹ stɛɹɪŋ ət ɹænd. blʌd tʃɹɪkəl fɹəm ɪz noʊz. "ju woʊnt ɡɛɾ əweɪ," hi spæɾ æŋɡɹəli. "noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ stʃɹɔŋ jə ɑɹ, ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk ɪz stʃɹɔŋɝ. ðə ʃædoʊ wɪl swɑloʊ ju!"

The Darkfriend fell on his bottom and sat there on the floor staring at Rand. Blood trickled from his nose. "You won't get away," he spat angrily. "No matter how strong you are, the Great Lord of the Dark is stronger. The Shadow will swallow you!"

ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡæsp fɹəm fɝðɝ ɪndə ðə kɑmən ɹum, ən ðə klæɾɝ ʌv ə bɹum hændəl hɪɾɪŋ ðə flɔɹ. ði oʊl mæn wɪð ðə bɹum hæd faɪnəli hɝd. hi stʊd stɛɹɪŋ waɪd-aɪɾ ət peɪtʃɹ. ðə blʌd dʒɹeɪn fɹəm ɪz ɹɪŋkəl feɪs ən ɪz maʊθ wɝkt, bʌt noʊ saʊn keɪm aʊt. peɪtʃɹ stɛɹd bæk fəɹ ən ɪnstənt, ðən ɡeɪv ə waɪl kɝs ən spɹæŋ tə hɪz fit, dɑɹɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ɪn ən daʊn ðə stʃɹiɾ əz ɪf stɑɹvɪŋ wʊlvz wɝ əɾ ɪz hilz. ði oʊl mæn ʃɪftəɾ ɪz ətɛnʃən tə ɹænd ən mæt, lʊkɪŋ nɑɾ ə wɪt lɛs fɹaɪɾənd.

There was a gasp from further into the common room, and the clatter of a broom handle hitting the floor. The old man with the broom had finally heard. He stood staring wide-eyed at Paitr. The blood drained from his wrinkled face and his mouth worked, but no sound came out. Paitr stared back for an instant, then gave a wild curse and sprang to his feet, darting out of the inn and down the street as if starving wolves were at his heels. The old man shifted his attention to Rand and Mat, looking not a whit less frightened.

ɹænd hʌsəl mæt aʊɾ ə ði ɪn ən aʊɾ ə ðə vɪlədʒ əz fæst əz i kʊd, lɪsnɪŋ ɔl ðə waɪl fəɹ ə hju ən kɹaɪ ðət nɛvɝ keɪm bʌt wɑz noʊ lɛs laʊɾ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz fəɹ ðæt.

Rand hustled Mat out of the inn and out of the village as fast as he could, listening all the while for a hue and cry that never came but was no less loud in his ears for that.

"blʌɾ ən æʃəz," mæt ɡɹaʊld, "ðeɪɹ ɔlweɪz ðɛɹ, ɔlweɪz ɹaɪɾ ɑn əɹ hilz. wɪl nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ əweɪ."

"Blood and ashes," Mat growled, "they're always there, always right on our heels. We'll never get away."

"noʊ ðəɹ nɑt," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪf bælzəmən nu wi wɝ hɪɹ, dʒju θɪŋk hiɾ əv lɛft ɪt tə ðət fɛloʊ? ðɛɹəɾ əv bɪn ənʌðɝ ɡoʊd, ən twɛnti əɹ θɝɾi bʊlɪbɔɪz. ðəɹ stɪl hʌntɪŋ, bʌt ðeɪ woʊnt noʊ əntɪl peɪtʃɹ tɛlz ðɛm, ən meɪbi hi ɹɪli ɪz əloʊn. hi maɪɾ əv tə ɡoʊ ɔl ðə weɪ tə fɔɹ kɪŋz, fəɹ ɔl wi noʊ."

"No they're not," Rand said. "If Ba'alzamon knew we were here, do you think he'd have left it to that fellow? There'd have been another Gode, and twenty or thirty bullyboys. They're still hunting, but they won't know until Paitr tells them, and maybe he really is alone. He might have to go all the way to Four Kings, for all we know."

"bʌɾ i sɛd - "

"But he said - "

"aɪ doʊn kɛɹ." hi wɑz ənʃʊɹ wɪtʃ "hi" mæt mɛnt, bʌɾ ɪt tʃeɪnʒd nʌθɪŋ. "wɝ nɑt gɑnə laɪ daʊn ən lɛɾ əm teɪk ʌs."

"I don't care." He was unsure which "he" Mat meant, but it changed nothing. "We're not going to lie down and let them take us."

ðeɪ ɡɑt sɪks ɹaɪdz, ʃɔɹt wʌnz, dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪ. ə fɑɹmɝ toʊld əm ðəɾ ə kɹeɪzi oʊl mæn ət ði ɪn ɪn mɑɹkət ʃɛɹən wɑz kleɪmɪŋ ðəɹ wɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪn ðə vɪlədʒ. ðə fɑɹmɝ kəd hɑɹdli tɔk fəɹ læfɪŋ; hi kɛpt waɪpɪŋ tɪɹz ɔf ɪz tʃiks. dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɪn mɑɹkət ʃɛɹən! ɪt wɑz ðə bɛst stɔɹi hi hæd hɝd sɪns ækli fɛɹən ɡɑt dʒɹʌŋk ən spɛn ðə naɪɾ ɑn ði ɪn ɹuf.

They got six rides, short ones, during the day. A farmer told them that a crazy old man at the inn in Market Sheran was claiming there were Darkfriends in the village. The farmer could hardly talk for laughing; he kept wiping tears off his cheeks. Darkfriends in Market Sheran! It was the best story he had heard since Ackley Farren got drunk and spent the night on the inn roof.

ənʌðɝ mæn, ə ɹaʊnd-feɪst wæɡoʊnɹaɪt wɪð tulz hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ðə saɪdz ə hɪz kɑɹɾ ən tu wæɡən wilz ɪn ðə bæk, toʊld ə dɪfɹən stɔɹi. twɛnti dɑɹkfɹɛnz hæd hɛld ə ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪn mɑɹkət ʃɛɹən. mɛn wɪð twɪstəd bɑɾiz, ən ðə wɪmən wɝs, ɔl dɝɾi ən ɪn ɹæɡz. ðeɪ kəd meɪk jəɹ niz ɡɹoʊ wik ən jəɹ stʌmək hiv dʒʌs baɪ lʊkɪŋ ət ju, ən wən ðeɪ læft, ðə fɪlθi kækəlz ɹæŋ ɪn jəɹ ɪɹz fəɹ aʊɝz ən jəɹ hɛd fɛlt əz ɪf ɪt wɝ splɪɾɪŋ oʊpən. hi hæd sin əm hɪmsɛlf, dʒʌst əɾ ə dɪstəns, fɑɹ ɪnʌf ɔf tə bi seɪf. ɪf ðə kwin wəd nɑt də sʌmθɪŋ, ðən sʌmbɑɾi ɔt tə æsk ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt fəɹ hɛlp. sʌmbɑɾi ʃəd də sʌmθɪŋ.

Another man, a round-faced wagonwright with tools hanging from the sides of his cart and two wagon wheels in the back, told a different story. Twenty Darkfriends had held a gathering in Market Sheran. Men with twisted bodies, and the women worse, all dirty and in rags. They could make your knees grow weak and your stomach heave just by looking at you, and when they laughed, the filthy cackles rang in your ears for hours and your head felt as if it were splitting open. He had seen them himself, just at a distance, far enough off to be safe. If the Queen would not do something, then somebody ought to ask the Children of the Light for help. Somebody should do something.

ɪt wɑz ə ɹɪlif wən ðə wæɡoʊnɹaɪt lɛɾ əm daʊn.

It was a relief when the wagonwright let them down.

wɪð ðə sʌn loʊ bɪhaɪn əm ðeɪ wɔkt ɪndə ə smɔl vɪlədʒ, mʌtʃ laɪk mɑɹkət ʃɛɹən. ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd splɪt ðə taʊn nitli ɪn tu, bʌɾ ɑn boʊθ saɪdz ə ðə waɪd ɹoʊd stʊd ɹoʊz ə smɔl bɹɪk haʊsəz wɪð θætʃt ɹufs. wɛbz ə vaɪn kʌvɝd ðə bɹɪks, ðoʊ oʊnli ə fju livz hʌŋ ɑn ðɛm. ðə vɪlədʒ hæd wʌn ɪn, ə smɔl pleɪs noʊ bɪɡɝ ðən ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn, wɪð ə saɪn ɑn ə bɹækɪɾ aʊt fɹʌnt, kɹikɪŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ ɪn ðə wɪnd. ðə kwinz mæn.

With the sun low behind them they walked into a small village, much like Market Sheran. The Caemlyn Road split the town neatly in two, but on both sides of the wide road stood rows of small brick houses with thatched roofs. Webs of vine covered the bricks, though only a few leaves hung on them. The village had one inn, a small place no bigger than the Winespring Inn, with a sign on a bracket out front, creaking back and forth in the wind. The Queen's Man.

stʃɹeɪnʒ, tə θɪŋk ə ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn əz smɔl. ɹænd kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ wən i θɔɾ ɪt wɑz əbaʊɾ əz bɪɡ əz ə bɪldɪŋ kəd bi. ɛniθɪŋ bɪɡɝ wəd bi ə pæləs. bʌɾ i hæd sin ə fju θɪŋz, naʊ, ən sʌɾənli hi ɹilaɪz ðət nʌθɪŋ wəd lʊk ðə seɪm tə hɪm wən i ɡɑt bæk hoʊm. ɪf jə ɛvɝ du.

Strange, to think of the Winespring Inn as small. Rand could remember when he thought it was about as big as a building could be. Anything bigger would be a palace. But he had seen a few things, now, and suddenly he realized that nothing would look the same to him when he got back home. If you ever do.

hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd ɪn fɹʌn ə ði ɪn, bʌɾ ivən ɪf pɹaɪsəz ət ðə kwinz mæn wɝ nɑɾ əz haɪ əz ɪn mɑɹkət ʃɛɹən, ðeɪ kəd nɑɾ əfɔɹɾ ə mil əɹ ə ɹum, iðɝ wʌn.

He hesitated in front of the inn, but even if prices at The Queen's Man were not as high as in Market Sheran, they could not afford a meal or a room, either one.

mæt sɔ wɛɹ i wɑz lʊkɪŋ ən pæɾəd ðə pɑkət wɛɹ i kɛp tɑmz kʌlɝd bɔlz. "aɪ kən si wɛl ɪnʌf, əz lɔŋ əz aɪ doʊn tʃɹaɪ tə ɡɛt tu fænsi." hɪz aɪz hæd bɪn ɡɛɾɪŋ bɛɾɝ, ðoʊ hi stɪl wɔɹ ðə skɑɹf ɝaʊn ɪz fɔɹhɛd, ən hæd skwɪntɪd wɛnɛvɝ i lʊkt ət ðə skaɪ dʊɹɪŋ ðə deɪ. wən ɹænd sɛd nʌθɪŋ, mæt wɛn ɑn. "ðɛɹ kæn bi dɑɹkfɹɛnz əɾ ɛvɹi ɪn bɪtwin hɪɹ ən keɪɛmlɪn. bɪsaɪdz, aɪ doʊnt wɑnə slip ʌndɝ ə bʊʃ ɪf aɪ kən slip ɪn ə bɛd." hi meɪd noʊ muv təwɔɹd ði ɪn, ðoʊ, dʒʌst stʊd weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɹænd.

Mat saw where he was looking and patted the pocket where he kept Thom's colored balls. "I can see well enough, as long as I don't try to get too fancy." His eyes had been getting better, though he still wore the scarf around his forehead, and had squinted whenever he looked at the sky during the day. When Rand said nothing, Mat went on. "There can't be Darkfriends at every inn between here and Caemlyn. Besides, I don't want to sleep under a bush if I can sleep in a bed." He made no move toward the inn, though, just stood waiting for Rand.

æftɝ ə moʊmən ɹænd nɑɾəd. hi fɛlt əz taɪɝɾ əz i hæɾ əɾ ɛni taɪm sɪns livɪŋ hoʊm. dʒʌs θɪŋkɪŋ ʌv ə naɪɾ ɪn ði oʊpən meɪɾ ɪz boʊnz eɪk. ɪts ɔl kætʃɪŋ ʌp. ɔl ðə ɹʌnɪŋ, ɔl ðə lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ jəɹ ʃoʊldɝ.

After a moment Rand nodded. He felt as tired as he had at any time since leaving home. Just thinking of a night in the open made his bones ache. It's all catching up. All the running, all the looking over your shoulder.

"ðeɪ kæn bi ɛvɹiwɛɹ," hi əɡɹid.

"They can't be everywhere," he agreed.

wɪð ðə fɝst stɛp i tʊk ɪndə ðə kɑmən ɹum, hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf i hæd meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk. ɪt wɑz ə klin pleɪs, bʌt kɹaʊɾəd. ɛvɹi teɪbəl wɑz fɪld, ən səm mɛn lin əɡɛns ðə wɔlz kəz ðəɹ wɑz noʊwɛɹ fəɹ əm tə sɪt. fɹəm ðə weɪ ðə sɝvɪŋ meɪdz skɝid bɪtwin ðə teɪbəlz wɪð hɛɹid lʊks - ən ðə lændlɔɹd, tu - ɪt wɑz ə lɑɹdʒɝ kɹaʊd ðən ðeɪ wɝ juz tə. tu mɛni fəɹ ðɪs smɔl vɪlədʒ. ɪt wɑz izi tə pɪk aʊt ðə pipəl u dɪd nɑt bɪlɔŋ ðɛɹ. ðeɪ wɝ dʒɹɛs noʊ dɪfɹənli fɹəm ðə ɹɛst, bʌt ðeɪ kɛp ðɛɹ aɪz ɑn ðɛɹ fuɾ ən dʒɹɪŋk. ðə loʊkəlz wɑtʃt ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz əz mʌtʃ əz ɛniθɪŋ ɛls.

With the first step he took into the common room, he wondered if he had made a mistake. It was a clean place, but crowded. Every table was filled, and some men leaned against the walls because there was nowhere for them to sit. From the way the serving maids scurried between the tables with harried looks - and the landlord, too - it was a larger crowd than they were used to. Too many for this small village. It was easy to pick out the people who did not belong there. They were dressed no differently from the rest, but they kept their eyes on their food and drink. The locals watched the strangers as much as anything else.

ə dʒɹoʊn ə kɑnvɝseɪʃən hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, ɪnʌf ðət ði ɪnkipɝ tʊk əm ɪndə ðə kɪtʃən wən ɹænd meɪɾ ɪm ʌndɝstæn ðət ðeɪ niɾəd tə tɔk tə hɪm. ðə nɔɪz wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz bæd ðɛɹ, wɪð ðə kʊk ən ɪz hɛlpɝz bæŋɪŋ pɑts ən dɑɹɾɪŋ əbaʊt.

A drone of conversation hung in the air, enough that the innkeeper took them into the kitchen when Rand made him understand that they needed to talk to him. The noise was almost as bad there, with the cook and his helpers banging pots and darting about.

ði ɪnkipɝ mɑpt ɪz feɪs wɪð ə lɑɹdʒ hæŋkɝtʃɪf. "aɪ səpoʊz jəɹ ɑn jəɹ weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn tə si ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən laɪk ɛvɹi ʌðɝ ful ɪn ðə ɹɛlm. wɛl, ɪts sɪks tə ə ɹum ən tu əɹ θɹi tə ə bɛd, ən ɪf ðət dʌzn sut, aɪv nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ju."

The innkeeper mopped his face with a large handkerchief. "I suppose you're on your way to Caemlyn to see the false Dragon like every other fool in the Realm. Well, it's six to a room and two or three to a bed, and if that doesn't suit, I've nothing for you."

ɹænd ɡeɪv ɪz spil wɪð ə filɪŋ ə kwizinəs. wɪð soʊ mɛni pipəl ɑn ðə ɹoʊd, ɛvɹi ʌðɝ wʌn kəd bi ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə pɪk əm aʊt fɹəm ðə ɹɛst. mæt dɛmənstʃɹeɪɾəd ɪz dʒʌɡəlɪŋ - hi kɛpt ɪt tə θɹi bɔlz, ən wɑz kɛɹfəl ivən ðən - ən ɹænd tʊk aʊt tɑmz flut. æftɝ oʊnli ə dʌzən noʊts ʌv "ði oʊl blæk bɛɹ," ði ɪnkipɝ nɑɾəd ɪmpeɪʃənli.

Rand gave his spiel with a feeling of queasiness. With so many people on the road, every other one could be a Darkfriend, and there was no way to pick them out from the rest. Mat demonstrated his juggling - he kept it to three balls, and was careful even then - and Rand took out Thom's flute. After only a dozen notes of "The Old Black Bear," the innkeeper nodded impatiently.

"jul du. aɪ nid sʌmθɪŋ tə teɪk ðoʊz ɪɾiəts' maɪnz ɔf ðɪs lɑɡən. ðɛɹz bɪn θɹi faɪts ɔlɹɛɾi oʊvɝ wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt hiz ɹɪli ðə dʒɹæɡən. stoʊ jəɹ θɪŋz ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ, ən əl ɡoʊ klɪɹ ə speɪs fəɹ ju. ɪf ðɛɹz ɛni ɹum tə. fulz. ðə wɝlz fʊl ə fulz u doʊnt noʊ ɪnʌf tə steɪ wɛɹ ðeɪ bɪlɔŋ. ðæts wʌts kɑzɪŋ ɔl ðə tʃɹʌbəl. pipəl u woʊn steɪ wɛɹ ðeɪ bɪlɔŋ." mɑpɪŋ ɪz feɪs əɡɛn, hi hɝiɾ aʊɾ ə ðə kɪtʃən, mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ.

"You'll do. I need something to take those idiots' minds off this Logain. There's been three fights already over whether or not he's really the Dragon. Stow your things in the corner, and I'll go clear a space for you. If there's any room to. Fools. The world's full of fools who don't know enough to stay where they belong. That's what's causing all the trouble. People who won't stay where they belong." Mopping his face again, he hurried out of the kitchen, muttering under his breath.

ðə kʊk ən ɪz hɛlpɝz ɪɡnɔɹd ɹænd ən mæt. mæt kɛpt ədʒʌstɪŋ ðə skɑɹf ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd, pʊʃɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp, ðən blɪŋkɪŋ ət ðə laɪɾ ən tʌɡɪŋ ɪt bæk daʊn əɡɛn. ɹænd wʌndɝɾ ɪf i kəd si wɛl ɪnʌf tə də ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ kɑmpləkeɪɾəd ðən dʒʌɡəl θɹi bɔlz. əz fəɹ hɪmsɛlf. . . .

The cook and his helpers ignored Rand and Mat. Mat kept adjusting the scarf around his head, pushing it up, then blinking at the light and tugging it back down again. Rand wondered if he could see well enough to do anything more complicated than juggle three balls. As for himself. . . .

ðə kwizinəs ɪn ɪz stʌmək ɡɹu θɪkɝ. hi dʒɹɑpt ɑn ə loʊ stul, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn ɪz hænz. ðə kɪtʃən fɛl koʊld. hi ʃɪvɝd. stim fɪl ði ɛɹ; stoʊvz ən ʌvənz kɹækəld wɪð hit. hɪz ʃɪvɝz bɪkeɪm stʃɹɔŋɝ, hɪz tiθ tʃæɾɝɪŋ. hi ɹæpt ɪz ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɪmsɛlf, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd noʊ ɡʊd. hɪz boʊnz fɛlt əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ fɹizɪŋ.

The queasiness in his stomach grew thicker. He dropped on a low stool, holding his head in his hands. The kitchen felt cold. He shivered. Steam filled the air; stoves and ovens crackled with heat. His shivers became stronger, his teeth chattering. He wrapped his arms around himself, but it did no good. His bones felt as if they were freezing.

dɪmli hi wɑz əwɛɹ ə mæt æskɪŋ ɪm sʌmθɪŋ, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ən ə sʌmwʌn kɝsɪŋ ən ɹʌnɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum. ðən ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz ðɛɹ, wɪð ðə kʊk fɹaʊnɪŋ əɾ ɪz saɪd, ən mæt wɑz ɑɹɡjuɪŋ laʊdli wɪð əm boʊθ. hi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊɾ ɛni ʌv wʌt ðeɪ sɛd; ðə wɝdz wɝ ə bʌz ɪn ɪz ɪɹz, ən i kəd nɑt sim tə θɪŋk əɾ ɔl.

Dimly he was aware of Mat asking him something, shaking his shoulder, and of someone cursing and running out of the room. Then the innkeeper was there, with the cook frowning at his side, and Mat was arguing loudly with them both. He could not make out any of what they said; the words were a buzz in his ears, and he could not seem to think at all.

sʌɾənli mæt tʊk ɪz ɑɹm, pʊlɪŋ ɪm tə hɪz fit. ɔl ə ðɛɹ θɪŋz - sæɾəlbæɡz, blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊlz, tɑmz bʌndəl kloʊk ən ɪnstʃɹəmən keɪsəz - hʌŋ fɹəm mæts ʃoʊldɝz wɪð ɪz baʊ. ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ðɛm, waɪpɪŋ ɪz feɪs æŋkʃəsli. wivɪŋ, mɔɹ ðən hæf səpɔɹɾəd baɪ mæt, ɹænd lɛɾ ɪz fɹɛn stɪɹ ɪm təwɔɹd ðə bæk dɔɹ.

Suddenly Mat took his arm, pulling him to his feet. All of their things - saddlebags, blanketrolls, Thom's bundled cloak and instrument cases - hung from Mat's shoulders with his bow. The innkeeper was watching them, wiping his face anxiously. Weaving, more than half supported by Mat, Rand let his friend steer him toward the back door.

"ɛs-ɛs-sɑɹi, ɛm-ɛm-mæt," hi mænədʒd. hi kəd nɑt stɑp ɪz tiθ fɹəm tʃæɾɝɪŋ. "ɛm-ɛm-mʌst əv . . . bi-bɪn ti-ðə . . . ɹeɪn. oʊ-wʌn ɛm-mɔɹ . . . naɪɾ aʊt . . . dʌbəlju-woʊn eɪtʃ-hɝt . . . aɪ ɡɛs." twaɪlaɪt dɑɹkən ðə skaɪ, spɑɾəd baɪ ə hændfʊl ə stɑɹz.

"S-s-sorry, M-m-mat," he managed. He could not stop his teeth from chattering. "M-m-must have . . . b-been t-the . . . rain. O-one m-more . . . night out . . . w-won't h-hurt . . . I guess." Twilight darkened the sky, spotted by a handful of stars.

"nɑɾ ə bɪɾ ʌv ɪt," mæt sɛd. hi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə saʊn tʃɪɹfəl, bʌt ɹænd kəd hɪɹ ðə hɪɾən wɝi. "hi wɑz skɛɹd ði ʌðɝ foʊk wəd faɪn aʊt ðəɹ wɑz sʌmbɑɾi sɪk ɪn ɪz ɪn. aɪ toʊld ɪm ɪf i kɪkt əs aʊt, aɪd teɪk jə ɪndə ðə kɑmən ɹum. ðæɾəd ɛmpti hæf ɪz ɹumz ɪn tɛn mɪnəts. fəɹ ɔl ɪz tɔk əbaʊt fulz, hi dʌznt wɑn ðæt."

"Not a bit of it," Mat said. He was trying to sound cheerful, but Rand could hear the hidden worry. "He was scared the other folk would find out there was somebody sick in his inn. I told him if he kicked us out, I'd take you into the common room. That'd empty half his rooms in ten minutes. For all his talk about fools, he doesn't want that."

"ðɛn dʌbəlju-wɛɹ?"

"Then w-where?"
