This weather, the crops failing, cows drying up, calves and lambs born dead, or with two heads. Bloody ravens don't even wait for things to die. People are scared. They want somebody to blame. Dragon's Fang turning up on people's doors. Things creeping about in the night. Barns getting burned. Fellows around like that friend of Holdwin, scaring people. The Queen's got to do something before it's too late. You see that, don't you?" Rand made a noncommittal sound. It sounded as if they had been even luckier than he had thought to find this old man and his cart. They might not have gotten further than that last village if they had waited for daylight. Things creeping about in the night. He lifted up to look over the side of the cart at the darkness. Shadows and shapes seemed to writhe in the black. He dropped back before his imagination convinced him there was something there.

bʌn tʊk ɪt fəɹ əɡɹimənt. "ɹaɪt. ɪm ə ɡʊd kwinz mæn, ən əl stæn əɡɛnst ɛni hu tʃɹaɪ tə hɑɹm hɝ, bʌɾ aɪm ɹaɪt. jə teɪk ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn ən ðə lɔɹd ɡɔɪn, naʊ. ðɛɹz ə tʃeɪnʒ wʊdn hɑɹm ɛniθɪŋ, ən maɪt də səm ɡʊd. ʃʊɹ, aɪ noʊ wiv ɔlweɪz dʌn ɪt ðət weɪ ɪn ændɝ. sɛn ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ɔf tə tɑɹ vəlɑn tə stʌɾi wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ði ɛldəst sʌn ɔf tə stʌɾi wɪð ðə wɔɹɾɝz. aɪ bɪliv ɪn tʃɹədɪʃən, aɪ du, bʌt lʊk wʌɾ ɪt ɡɑɾ əs læs taɪm. luk dɛɾ ɪn ðə blaɪt bɪfɔɹ i wɑz ɛvɝ ənɔɪntəd fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd, ən tɪɡɹeɪn vænɪʃt - ɹʌn ɔf əɹ dɛd - wən ɪt keɪm taɪm fəɹ əɹ tə teɪk ðə θɹoʊn. stɪl tʃɹʌbəlɪŋ ʌs, ðæt.

Bunt took it for agreement. "Right. I'm a good Queen's man, and I'll stand against any who try to harm her, but I'm right. You take the Lady Elayne and the Lord Gawyn, now. There's a change wouldn't harm anything, and might do some good. Sure, I know we've always done it that way in Andor. Send the Daughter-Heir off to Tar Valon to study with the Aes Sedai, and the eldest son off to study with the Warders. I believe in tradition, I do, but look what it got us last time. Luc dead in the Blight before he was ever anointed First Prince of the Sword, and Tigraine vanished - run off or dead - when it came time for her to take the throne. Still troubling us, that.

"ðɛɹz səm seɪɪŋ ʃiz stɪl əlaɪv, jə noʊ, ðət mɔɹɡeɪs ɪzən ðə ɹaɪtfəl kwin. blʌɾi fulz. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌt hæpənd. ɹɪmɛmbɝ laɪk ɪt wɑz jɛstɝdeɪ. noʊ dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ tə teɪk ðə θɹoʊn wən ði oʊl kwin daɪd, ən ɛvɹi haʊs ɪn ændɝ skimɪŋ ən faɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə ɹaɪt. ən tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl dəmədʒɹd. jə wʊdn əv θɔt hid lɔst ɪz waɪf, hɪm hɑt tə fɪɡjɝ wɪtʃ haʊs wəd wɪn soʊ hi kəd mɛɹi əɡɛn ən bɪkʌm pɹɪns kɑnsɔɹɾ æftɝ ɔl. wɛl, hi mænədʒd ɪt, ðoʊ waɪ mɔɹɡeɪs tʃoʊz . . . ɑ, noʊ mæn noʊz ðə maɪn ʌv ə wʊmən, ən ə kwin ɪz twaɪs ə wʊmən, wɛd tə ə mæn, wɛd tə ðə lænd. hi ɡɑt wʌɾ i wɑntəd, ɛniweɪ, ɪf nɑt ðə weɪ hi wɑntəɾ ɪt.

"There's some saying she's still alive, you know, that Morgase isn't the rightful Queen. Bloody fools. I remember what happened. Remember like it was yesterday. No Daughter-Heir to take the throne when the old Queen died, and every House in Andor scheming and fighting for the right. And Taringail Damodred. You wouldn't have thought he'd lost his wife, him hot to figure which House would win so he could marry again and become Prince Consort after all. Well, he managed it, though why Morgase chose . . . ah, no man knows the mind of a woman, and a queen is twice a woman, wed to a man, wed to the land. He got what he wanted, anyway, if not the way he wanted it.

"bɹɔt kɛɹhin ɪndə ðə plɑɾɪŋ bɪfɔɹ i wɑz dʌn, ən jə noʊ haʊ ðəɾ ɛndəd. ðə tʃɹi tʃɑp daʊn, ən blæk-veɪld il kʌmɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl. wɛl, hi ɡɑt hɪmsɛlf disənli kɪld æftɝ hid fɑðɝɾ ɪleɪn ən ɡɔɪn, soʊ ðɛɹz ən ɛn tə ɪt, aɪ səpoʊz. bʌt waɪ sɛn əm tə tɑɹ vəlɑn? ɪts taɪm mɛn dɪdn θɪŋk ə ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə seɪm θɔɾ ɛnimɔɹ. ɪf ðeɪv ɡɑt tə ɡoʊ səm pleɪs ɛls tə lɝn wʌt ðeɪ nid, wɛl, ɪljənz ɡɑt laɪbɹɛɹiz əz ɡʊɾ əz tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ðəl titʃ ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn əz mʌtʃ əbaʊt ɹulɪŋ ən skimɪŋ əz ɛvɝ ðə wɪtʃəz kʊd. noʊbɑdi noʊz mɔɹ əbaʊt skimɪŋ ðən ən ɪliɑnɝ. ən ɪf ðə ɡɑɹdz kæn titʃ ðə lɔɹd ɡɔɪn ɪnʌf əbaʊt soʊlʒɝɪŋ, wɛl, ðeɪv soʊlʒɝz ɪn ɪljən, tu. ən ɪn ʃaɪnɝ, ən tiɹ, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. ɪm ə ɡʊd kwinz mæn, bʌɾ aɪ seɪ lɛts stɑp ɔl ðɪs tʃɹʌk wɪð tɑɹ vəlɑn. θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz ɪz lɔŋ ɪnʌf. tu lɔŋ. kwin mɔɹɡeɪs kən liɾ əs ən pʊt θɪŋz ɹaɪt wɪθaʊt hɛlp fɹəm ðə waɪt taʊɝ. aɪ tɛl ju, ðɛɹz ə wʊmən meɪks ə mæn pɹaʊd tə nil fəɹ əɹ blɛsɪŋ. waɪ, wʌns. . . ."

"Brought Cairhien into the plotting before he was done, and you know how that ended. The Tree chopped down, and black-veiled Aiel coming over the Dragonwall. Well, he got himself decently killed after he'd fathered Elayne and Gawyn, so there's an end to it, I suppose. But why send them to Tar Valon? It's time men didn't think of the throne of Andor and Aes Sedai in the same thought anymore. If they've got to go some place else to learn what they need, well, Illian's got libraries as good as Tar Valon, and they'll teach the Lady Elayne as much about ruling and scheming as ever the witches could. Nobody knows more about scheming than an Illianer. And if the Guards can't teach the Lord Gawyn enough about soldiering, well, they've soldiers in Illian, too. And in Shienar, and Tear, for that matter. I'm a good Queen's man, but I say let's stop all this truck with Tar Valon. Three thousand years is long enough. Too long. Queen Morgase can lead us and put things right without help from the White Tower. I tell you, there's a woman makes a man proud to kneel for her blessing. Why, once. . . ."

ɹænd fɔt ðə slip ɪz bɑɾi kɹaɪɾ aʊt fɔɹ, bʌt ðə ɹɪðmɪk kɹik ən sweɪ ʌv ðə kɑɹt lʌld ɪm ən i floʊɾəd ɔf ɑn ðə dʒɹoʊn ə bʌns vɔɪs. hi dʒɹimd ə tæm. ət fɝs ðeɪ wɝ ət ðə bɪɡ oʊk teɪbəl ɪn ðə fɑɹmhaʊs, dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ ti waɪl tæm toʊld ɪm əbaʊt pɹɪns kɑnsɔɹts, ən dɔɾɝ-ɛɹz, ən ðə dʒɹæɡoʊnwɔl, ən blæk-veɪld ilmɛn. ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk sɔɹd leɪ ɑn ðə teɪbəl bɪtwin ðɛm, bʌt niðɝ ə ðɛm lʊkt əɾ ɪt. sʌɾənli hi wɑz ɪn ðə wɛstwʊd, pʊlɪŋ ðə meɪkʃɪf lɪɾɝ θɹu ðə mun-bɹaɪt naɪt. wən i lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ɪt wɑz tɑm ɑn ðə lɪɾɝ, nɑɾ ɪz fɑðɝ, sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəɾ ən dʒʌɡəlɪŋ ɪn ðə munlaɪt.

Rand fought the sleep his body cried out for, but the rhythmic creak and sway of the cart lulled him and he floated off on the drone of Bunt's voice. He dreamed of Tam. At first they were at the big oak table in the farmhouse, drinking tea while Tam told him about Prince Consorts, and Daughter-Heirs, and the Dragonwall, and black-veiled Aielmen. The heron-mark sword lay on the table between them, but neither of them looked at it. Suddenly he was in the Westwood, pulling the makeshift litter through the moon-bright night. When he looked over his shoulder, it was Thom on the litter, not his father, sitting cross-legged and juggling in the moonlight.

"ðə kwin ɪz wɛd tə ðə lænd," tɑm sɛɾ əz bɹaɪtli kʌlɝd bɔlz dænst ɪn ə sɝkəl, "bʌt ðə dʒɹæɡən . . . ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪz wʌn wɪð ðə lænd, ən ðə læn ɪz wʌn wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən."

"The Queen is wed to the land," Thom said as brightly colored balls danced in a circle, "but the Dragon . . . the Dragon is one with the land, and the land is one with the Dragon."

fɝðɝ bæk ɹænd sɔ ə feɪd kʌmɪŋ, blæk kloʊk ʌndɪstɝbd baɪ ðə wɪnd, hɔɹs ɡoʊstɪŋ saɪlənli θɹu ðə tʃɹiz. tu sɛvɝd hɛdz hʌŋ ət ðə mɹdʒɹɑlz sæɾəlboʊ, dʒɹɪpɪŋ blʌd ðət ɹæn ɪn dɑɹkɝ stʃɹimz daʊn ɪts maʊns koʊl-blæk ʃoʊldɝ. læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn, feɪsəz dɪstɔɹɾəd ɪn ɡɹɪməsɪz ə peɪn. ðə feɪd pʊld ɑn ə fɪsfəl ə tɛðɝz əz ɪt ɹoʊd. itʃ tɛðɝ ɹæn bæk tə ðə baʊn ɹɪsts ʌv wʌn ə ðoʊz u ɹæn bɪhaɪn ðə saʊnləs hʊvz, ðɛɹ feɪsəz blæŋk wɪð dɪspɛɹ. mæt ən pɛɹɪn. ən ɛɡwin.

Further back Rand saw a Fade coming, black cloak undisturbed by the wind, horse ghosting silently through the trees. Two severed heads hung at the Myrddraal's saddlebow, dripping blood that ran in darker streams down its mount's coal-black shoulder. Lan and Moiraine, faces distorted in grimaces of pain. The Fade pulled on a fistful of tethers as it rode. Each tether ran back to the bound wrists of one of those who ran behind the soundless hooves, their faces blank with despair. Mat and Perrin. And Egwene.

"nɑt hɝ!" ɹænd ʃaʊɾəd. "ðə laɪt blæs ju, ɪts mi jə wɑnt, nɑt hɝ!"

"Not her!" Rand shouted. "The Light blast you, it's me you want, not her!"

ðə hæfmən dʒɛstʃɝd, ən fleɪmz kənsumd ɛɡwin, flɛʃ kɹɪspɪŋ tə æʃ, boʊn blækɪŋ ən kɹʌmbəlɪŋ.

The Halfman gestured, and flames consumed Egwene, flesh crisping to ash, bone blacking and crumbling.

"ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪz wʌn wɪð ðə lænd," tɑm sɛd, stɪl dʒʌɡəlɪŋ ʌnkənsɝnədli, "æn ðə læn ɪz wʌn wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡən."

"The Dragon is one with the land," Thom said, still juggling unconcernedly, "and the land is one with the Dragon."

ɹænd skɹimd . . . ən oʊpən ɪz aɪz.

Rand screamed . . . and opened his eyes.

ðə kɑɹt kɹikt əlɔŋ ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd, fɪld wɪð naɪɾ ən ðə switnəs ə lɔŋ-vænɪʃt heɪ ən ðə feɪn smɛl ə hɔɹs. ə ʃeɪp blækɝ ðən ðə naɪt ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ɪz tʃɛst, ən aɪz blækɝ ðən dɛθ lʊkt ɪndə hɪz.

The cart creaked along the Caemlyn Road, filled with night and the sweetness of long-vanished hay and the faint smell of horse. A shape blacker than the night rested on his chest, and eyes blacker than death looked into his.

"ju ɑɹ maɪn," ðə ɹeɪvən sɛd, ən ðə ʃɑɹp bik stæbd ɪndə hɪz aɪ. hi skɹimd əz ɪt plʌkt ɪz aɪbɔl aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd.

"You are mine," the raven said, and the sharp beak stabbed into his eye. He screamed as it plucked his eyeball out of his head.

wɪð ə θɹoʊt-ɹɪpɪŋ ʃɹik, hi sæɾ ʌp, klæpɪŋ boʊθ hænz tə hɪz feɪs.

With a throat-ripping shriek, he sat up, clapping both hands to his face.

ɝli mɔɹnɪŋ deɪlaɪt beɪðd ðə kɑɹt. deɪzd, hi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪz hænz. noʊ blʌd. noʊ peɪn. ðə ɹɛst ə ðə dʒɹim wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi feɪɾɪŋ, bʌt ðæt. . . . dʒɪnʒɝli hi fɛlt ɪz feɪs ən ʃʌɾɝəd.

Early morning daylight bathed the cart. Dazed, he stared at his hands. No blood. No pain. The rest of the dream was already fading, but that. . . . Gingerly he felt his face and shuddered.

"æt list. . . ." mæt jɔnd, kɹækɪŋ ɪz dʒɔz. "æt lis jə ɡɑt səm slip." ðəɹ wɑz lɪɾəl sɪmpəθi ɪn ɪz blɪɹi aɪz. hi wɑz hʌɾəld ʌndɝ ɪz kloʊk, wɪð ɪz blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl dʌbəld ʌp bɪniθ ɪz hɛd. "hi tɔkt ɔl blʌɾi naɪt."

"At least. . . ." Mat yawned, cracking his jaws. "At least you got some sleep." There was little sympathy in his bleary eyes. He was huddled under his cloak, with his blanketroll doubled up beneath his head. "He talked all bloody night."

"ju ɔl ðə weɪ əweɪk?" bʌn sɛd fɹəm ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz sit. "ɡeɪv mi ə stɑɹt, jə dɪd, jɛlɪŋ laɪk ðæt. wɛl, wɝ ðɛɹ." hi swɛpt ə hæn aʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðɛm ɪn ə ɡɹæn dʒɛstʃɝ. "keɪɛmlɪn, ðə ɡɹændəst sɪɾi ɪn ðə wɝld."

"You all the way awake?" Bunt said from the driver's seat. "Gave me a start, you did, yelling like that. Well, we're there." He swept a hand out in front of them in a grand gesture. "Caemlyn, the grandest city in the world."


tʃæptɝ θɝɾifaɪv


CHAPTER 35

keɪɛmlɪn


Caemlyn

ɹænd twɪstəɾ ʌp tə nil bɪhaɪn ðə dʒɹaɪvɝz sit. hi kəd nɑt hɛlp læfɪŋ wɪð ɹɪlif. "wi meɪɾ ɪt, mæt! aɪ toʊl jə wid. . . ." wɝdz daɪɾ ɪn ɪz maʊθ əz ɪz aɪz fɛl ɑn keɪɛmlɪn. æftɝ bɛɹlən, ivən mɔɹ æftɝ ðə ɹuənz ə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, hi hæd θɔɾ i nu wʌɾ ə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾi wəd lʊk laɪk, bʌt ðɪs . . . ðɪs wɑz mɔɹ ðən i wəɾ əv bɪlivd.

Rand twisted up to kneel behind the driver's seat. He could not help laughing with relief. "We made it, Mat! I told you we'd. . . ." Words died in his mouth as his eyes fell on Caemlyn. After Baerlon, even more after the ruins of Shadar Logoth, he had thought he knew what a great city would look like, but this . . . this was more than he would have believed.

aʊtsaɪd ðə ɡɹeɪt wɔl, bɪldɪŋz klʌstɝɾ əz ɪf ɛvɹi taʊn i hæd pæs θɹu hæd bɪn ɡæðɝɾ ən sɛt daʊn ðɛɹ, saɪd-baɪ-saɪɾ ən ɔl pʊʃt təɡɛðɝ. ɪnz θɹʌs ðɛɹ ʌpɝ stɔɹiz əbʌv ðə taɪl ɹufs ə haʊsəz, ən skwɑt wɛɹhaʊzɪz, bɹɔɾ ən wɪndoʊləs, ʃoʊldɝɾ əɡɛnst əm ɔl. ɹɛd bɹɪk ən ɡɹeɪ stoʊn ən plæstɝd waɪt, dʒʌmbəld ən mɪks təɡɛðɝ, ðeɪ spɹɛɾ əz fɑɹ əz ði aɪ kəd si. bɛɹlən cʊɾə vænɪʃt ɪndə ɪt wɪθaʊt biɪŋ noʊɾəst, ən waɪtbɹɪdʒ swɑloʊɾ ʌp twɛnti taɪmz oʊvɝ wɪð hɑɹdli ə ɹɪpəl.

Outside the great wall, buildings clustered as if every town he had passed through had been gathered and set down there, side-by-side and all pushed together. Inns thrust their upper stories above the tile roofs of houses, and squat warehouses, broad and windowless, shouldered against them all. Red brick and gray stone and plastered white, jumbled and mixed together, they spread as far as the eye could see. Baerlon could have vanished into it without being noticed, and Whitebridge swallowed up twenty times over with hardly a ripple.

ən ðə wɔl ɪtsɛlf. ðə ʃɪɹ, fɪfti-fʊt haɪɾ ə peɪl ɡɹeɪ stoʊn, stʃɹikt wɪð sɪlvɝ ən waɪt, swɛpt aʊɾ ɪn ə ɡɹeɪt sɝkəl, kɝvɪŋ tə nɔɹθ ən saʊθ tɪl i wʌndɝd haʊ fɑɹ ɪt mʌst ɹʌn. ɔl əlɔŋ ɪts lɛŋθ taʊɝz ɹoʊz, ɹaʊn ən stændɪŋ haɪ əbʌv ðə wɔlz oʊn haɪt, ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt bænɝz wɪpɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪn ətɑp itʃ wʌn. fɹəm ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔl ʌðɝ taʊɝz pikt aʊt, slɛndɝ taʊɝz ivən tɔlɝ ðən ðoʊz ət ðə wɔlz, ən doʊmz ɡlimɪŋ waɪɾ ən ɡoʊld ɪn ðə sʌn. ə θaʊzən stɔɹiz hæd peɪntəd sɪɾiz ɪn ɪz maɪnd, ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾiz ə kɪŋz ən kwinz, ʌv θɹoʊnz ən paʊɝz ən lɛdʒənz, ən keɪɛmlɪn fɪɾ ɪndə ðoʊz maɪnd-dip pɪktʃɝz əz wɔɾɝ fɪts ɪndə ə dʒʌɡ.

And the wall itself. The sheer, fifty-foot height of pale gray stone, streaked with silver and white, swept out in a great circle, curving to north and south till he wondered how far it must run. All along its length towers rose, round and standing high above the wall's own height, red-and-white banners whipping in the wind atop each one. From inside the wall other towers peeked out, slender towers even taller than those at the walls, and domes gleaming white and gold in the sun. A thousand stories had painted cities in his mind, the great cities of kings and queens, of thrones and powers and legends, and Caemlyn fit into those mind-deep pictures as water fits into a jug.

ðə kɑɹt kɹik daʊn ðə waɪd ɹoʊd təwɔɹd ðə sɪɾi, təwɔɹd taʊɝ-flæŋkt ɡeɪts. ðə wæɡənz ʌv ə mɝtʃəns' tʃɹeɪn ɹoʊld aʊɾ ə ðoʊz ɡeɪts, ʌndɝ ə vɔltɪŋ ɑɹtʃweɪ ɪn ðə stoʊn ðət cʊɾə lɛɾ ə dʒaɪən θɹu, əɹ tɛn dʒaɪəns əbɹɛst. ənwɔl mɑɹkəts laɪn ðə ɹoʊɾ ɑn boʊθ saɪdz, ɹuf taɪlz ɡlɪsnɪŋ ɹɛɾ ən pɝpəl, wɪð stɔlz ən pɛnz ɪn ðə speɪsəz bɪtwin. kævz bɔld, kæɾəl loʊd, ɡis hɔŋkt, tʃɪkənz klʌkt, ɡoʊts bliɾɪd, ʃip beɪd, ən pipəl bɑɹɡən ət ðə tɑp ə ðɛɹ lʌŋz. ə wɔl ə nɔɪz fʌnəld əm təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪts ə keɪɛmlɪn.

The cart creaked down the wide road toward the city, toward tower-flanked gates. The wagons of a merchants' train rolled out of those gates, under a vaulting archway in the stone that could have let a giant through, or ten giants abreast. Unwalled markets lined the road on both sides, roof tiles glistening red and purple, with stalls and pens in the spaces between. Calves bawled, cattle lowed, geese honked, chickens clucked, goats bleated, sheep baaed, and people bargained at the top of their lungs. A wall of noise funneled them toward the gates of Caemlyn.

"wʌt dɪɾ aɪ tɛl ju?" bʌn hæd tə ɹeɪz ɪz vɔɪs tə nɪɹ ə ʃaʊɾ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə bi hɝd. "ðə ɡɹændəst sɪɾi ɪn ðə wɝld. bɪl baɪ oʊɡiɝ, jə noʊ. list, ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi ən ðə pæləs wɝ. ɪts ðəɾ oʊld, keɪɛmlɪn ɪz. keɪɛmlɪn, wɛɹ ɡʊd kwin mɔɹɡeɪs, ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin hɝ, meɪks ðə lɔ ən hoʊlz ðə pis fəɹ ændɝ. ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst sɪɾi ɑn ɝθ."

"What did I tell you?" Bunt had to raise his voice to near a shout in order to be heard. "The grandest city in the world. Built by Ogier, you know. Least, the Inner City and the Palace were. It's that old, Caemlyn is. Caemlyn, where good Queen Morgase, the Light illumine her, makes the law and holds the peace for Andor. The greatest city on earth."

ɹænd wɑz ɹɛɾi tə əɡɹi. hɪz maʊθ hʌŋ oʊpən, ən i wɑntəd tə pʊɾ ɪz hænz oʊvɝ ɪz ɪɹz tə ʃʌɾ aʊt ðə dɪn. pipəl kɹaʊɾəd ðə ɹoʊd, əz θɪk əz foʊk ɪn ɛmənz fil kɹaʊɾəd ðə ɡɹin ət bɛl taɪn. hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd θɪŋkɪŋ ðəɹ wɝ tu mɛni pipəl ɪn bɛɹlən tə bi bɪlivd, ən ɔlmoʊs læft. hi lʊkt ət mæt ən ɡɹɪnd. mæt dɪɾ əv ɪz hænz oʊvɝ ɪz ɪɹz, ən ɪz ʃoʊldɝz wɝ hʌntʃt ʌp əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə kʌvɝ əm wɪð ðoʊz, tu.

Rand was ready to agree. His mouth hung open, and he wanted to put his hands over his ears to shut out the din. People crowded the road, as thick as folk in Emond's Field crowded the Green at Bel Tine. He remembered thinking there were too many people in Baerlon to be believed, and almost laughed. He looked at Mat and grinned. Mat did have his hands over his ears, and his shoulders were hunched up as if he wanted to cover them with those, too.

"haʊ ɑɹ wi gɑnə haɪɾ ɪn ðɪs?" hi dɪmændəd laʊdli wən i sɔ ɹænd lʊkɪŋ. "haʊ kən wi tɛl u tə tʃɹʌst wɪð soʊ mɛni? soʊ blʌɾi mɛni. laɪt, ðə nɔɪz!"

"How are we going to hide in this?" he demanded loudly when he saw Rand looking. "How can we tell who to trust with so many? So bloody many. Light, the noise!"

ɹænd lʊkt ət bʌn bɪfɔɹ ænsɝɪŋ. ðə fɑɹmɝ wɑz kɑɾ ʌp ɪn stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə sɪɾi; wɪð ðə nɔɪz, hi maɪt nɑɾ əv hɝɾ ɛniweɪ. stɪl, ɹænd pʊɾ ɪz maʊθ kloʊs tə mæts ɪɹ. "haʊ kən ðeɪ faɪn əs əmʌŋ soʊ mɛni? kæn jə si ɪt, jə wʊl-hɛɾəd ɪɾiət? wɝ seɪf, ɪf jə ɛvɝ lɝn tə wɑtʃ jəɹ blʌɾi tʌŋ!" hi flʌŋ aʊɾ ə hæn tə teɪk ɪn ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ðə mɑɹkəts, ðə sɪɾi wɔlz stɪl əhɛd. "lʊk əɾ ɪt, mæt! ɛniθɪŋ kəd hæpən hɪɹ. ɛniθɪŋ! wi maɪɾ ivən faɪn mɔɪɹeɪn weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ʌs, ən ɛɡwin, ən ɔl ðə ɹɛst."

Rand looked at Bunt before answering. The farmer was caught up in staring at the city; with the noise, he might not have heard anyway. Still, Rand put his mouth close to Mat's ear. "How can they find us among so many? Can't you see it, you wool-headed idiot? We're safe, if you ever learn to watch your bloody tongue!" He flung out a hand to take in everything, the markets, the city walls still ahead. "Look at it, Mat! Anything could happen here. Anything! We might even find Moiraine waiting for us, and Egwene, and all the rest."

"ɪf ðəɹ əlaɪv. ɪf jə æsk mi, ðəɹ əz dɛɾ əz ðə ɡlimən."

"If they're alive. If you ask me, they're as dead as the gleeman."

ðə ɡɹɪn feɪɾəd fɹəm ɹændz feɪs, ən i tɝn tə wɑtʃ ðə ɡeɪts kʌm nɪɹɝ. ɛniθɪŋ kəd hæpən ɪn ə sɪɾi laɪk keɪɛmlɪn. hi hɛl ðət θɔt stʌbɝnli.

The grin faded from Rand's face, and he turned to watch the gates come nearer. Anything could happen in a city like Caemlyn. He held that thought stubbornly.

ðə hɔɹs kəd nɑt muv ɛni fæstɝ, flæp ðə ɹeɪnz əz bʌnt wʊd; ðə kloʊsɝ tə ðə ɡeɪts ðeɪ keɪm, ðə θɪkɝ ðə kɹaʊd ɡɹu, dʒɑsəlɪŋ təɡɛðɝ ʃoʊldɝ tə ʃoʊldɝ, pɹɛsɪŋ əɡɛns ðə kɑɹts ən wæɡənz hɛɾɪŋ ɪn. ɹænd wɑz ɡlæd tə si ə ɡʊd mɛni wɝ dʌsti jʌŋ mɛn əfʊt wɪð lɪɾəl ɪn ðə weɪ ʌv bɪlɔŋɪŋz. wʌtɛvɝ ðɛɹ eɪdʒəz, ə lɑɾ ə ðə kɹaʊd pʊʃɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪts hæɾ ə tʃɹævəl-wɔɹn lʊk, ɹɪkəɾi kɑɹts ən taɪɝd hɔɹsəz, kloʊðz ɹɪŋkəl fɹəm mɛni naɪts ə slipɪŋ ɹʌf, dʒɹæɡɪŋ stɛps ən wɪɹi aɪz. bʌt wɪɹi əɹ nɑt, ðoʊz aɪz wɝ fɪkst ɑn ðə ɡeɪts əz ɪf ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz wəd stʃɹɪp əweɪ ɔl ðɛɹ fətiɡ.

The horse could not move any faster, flap the reins as Bunt would; the closer to the gates they came, the thicker the crowd grew, jostling together shoulder to shoulder, pressing against the carts and wagons heading in. Rand was glad to see a good many were dusty young men afoot with little in the way of belongings. Whatever their ages, a lot of the crowd pushing toward the gates had a travel-worn look, rickety carts and tired horses, clothes wrinkled from many nights of sleeping rough, dragging steps and weary eyes. But weary or not, those eyes were fixed on the gates as if getting inside the walls would strip away all their fatigue.

hæf ə dʌzən ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz stʊɾ ət ðə ɡeɪts, ðɛɹ klin ɹɛd-ænd-waɪt tɑbɝdz ən bɝnɪʃt pleɪt-ænd-meɪl ə ʃɑɹp kɑntʃɹæs tə moʊst ə ðə pipəl stʃɹimɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə stoʊn ɑɹtʃ. bæks ɹɪdʒəɾ ən hɛdz stʃɹeɪt, ðeɪ aɪd ði ɪnkoʊmɝz wɪð dɪsdeɪnfəl wɛɹinɪs. ɪt wɑz pleɪn ðeɪ wəd dʒʌst əz sun əv tɝn əweɪ moʊst ə ðoʊz kʌmɪŋ ɪn. əsaɪd fɹəm kipɪŋ ə weɪ klɪɹ fəɹ tʃɹæfɪk livɪŋ ðə sɪɾi, ðoʊ, ən hævɪŋ ə hɑɹd wɝd wɪð ðoʊz u tʃɹaɪd tə pʊʃ tu fæst, ðeɪ dɪd nɑt hɪndɝ ɛniwʌn.

Half a dozen of the Queen's Guards stood at the gates, their clean red-and-white tabards and burnished plate-and-mail a sharp contrast to most of the people streaming under the stone arch. Backs rigid and heads straight, they eyed the incomers with disdainful wariness. It was plain they would just as soon have turned away most of those coming in. Aside from keeping a way clear for traffic leaving the city, though, and having a hard word with those who tried to push too fast, they did not hinder anyone.

"kip jəɹ pleɪsəz. doʊn pʊʃ. doʊn pʊʃ, ðə laɪt blaɪn ju! ðɛɹz ɹum fəɹ ɛvɹibɑɾi, ðə laɪt hɛlp ʌs. kip jəɹ pleɪsəz."

"Keep your places. Don't push. Don't push, the Light blind you! There's room for everybody, the Light help us. Keep your places."

bʌns kɑɹt ɹoʊl pæs ðə ɡeɪts wɪð ðə sloʊ taɪɾ ə ðə θɹɔŋ, ɪndə keɪɛmlɪn.

Bunt's cart rolled past the gates with the slow tide of the throng, into Caemlyn.

ðə sɪɾi ɹoʊz ɑn loʊ hɪlz, laɪk stɛps klaɪmɪŋ tə ə sɛntɝ. ənʌðɝ wɔl ɪnsɝkəl ðət sɛntɝ, ʃaɪnɪŋ pjʊɹ waɪɾ ən ɹʌnɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə hɪlz. ɪnsaɪd ðət wɝ ivən mɔɹ taʊɝz ən doʊmz, waɪɾ ən ɡoʊld ən pɝpəl, ðɛɹ ɛləveɪʃən ətɑp ðə hɪlz meɪkɪŋ əm sim tə lʊk daʊn ɑn ðə ɹɛst ə keɪɛmlɪn. ɹænd θɔt ðət mʌs bi ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi ʌv wɪtʃ bʌn hæd spoʊkən.

The city rose on low hills, like steps climbing to a center. Another wall encircled that center, shining pure white and running over the hills. Inside that were even more towers and domes, white and gold and purple, their elevation atop the hills making them seem to look down on the rest of Caemlyn. Rand thought that must be the Inner City of which Bunt had spoken.

ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊɾ ɪtsɛlf tʃeɪnʒd əz sun əz ɪt wɑz ɪnsaɪd ðə sɪɾi, bɪkʌmɪŋ ə waɪd bʊləvɑɹd, splɪt daʊn ðə mɪɾəl baɪ bɹɔd stʃɹɪps ʌv ɡɹæs ən tʃɹiz. ðə ɡɹæs wɑz bɹaʊn ən ðə tʃɹi bɹæntʃəz bɛɹ, bʌt pipəl hɝid baɪ əz ɪf ðeɪ sɔ nʌθɪŋ ənjuʒəwəl, læfɪŋ, tɔkɪŋ, ɑɹɡjuɪŋ, duɪŋ ɔl ðə θɪŋz ðət pipəl du. dʒʌst əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd noʊ aɪdiə ðət ðəɹ hæd bɪn noʊ spɹɪŋ jɛt ðɪs jɪɹ ən maɪt bi nʌn. ðeɪ dɪd nɑt si, ɹænd ɹilaɪzd, kəd nɑɾ əɹ wəd nɑt. ðɛɹ aɪz slɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm lifləs bɹæntʃəz, ən ðeɪ wɔkt əkɹɔs ðə dɛɾ ən daɪɪŋ ɡɹæs wɪθaʊt wʌns lʊkɪŋ daʊn. wʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt si, ðeɪ kəɾ ɪɡnɔɹ; wʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt si wɑz nɑt ɹɪli ðɛɹ.

The Caemlyn Road itself changed as soon as it was inside the city, becoming a wide boulevard, split down the middle by broad strips of grass and trees. The grass was brown and the tree branches bare, but people hurried by as if they saw nothing unusual, laughing, talking, arguing, doing all the things that people do. Just as if they had no idea that there had been no spring yet this year and might be none. They did not see, Rand realized, could not or would not. Their eyes slid away from leafless branches, and they walked across the dead and dying grass without once looking down. What they did not see, they could ignore; what they did not see was not really there.

ɡeɪpɪŋ ət ðə sɪɾi ən ðə pipəl, ɹænd wɑz teɪkən baɪ sɝpɹaɪz wən ðə kɑɹt tɝn daʊn ə saɪd stʃɹit, nɛɹoʊɝ ðən ðə bʊləvɑɹd, bʌt stɪl twaɪs əz waɪɾ əz ɛni stʃɹiɾ ɪn ɛmənz fild. bʌn dʒɹu ðə hɔɹs tə ə hɔlt ən tɝn tə lʊk bæk əɾ əm hɛzɪɾəntli. ðə tʃɹæfɪk wɑz ə bɪt laɪɾɝ hɪɹ; ðə kɹaʊd splɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə kɑɹt wɪθaʊt bɹeɪkɪŋ stʃɹaɪd.

Gaping at the city and the people, Rand was taken by surprise when the cart turned down a side street, narrower than the boulevard, but still twice as wide as any street in Emond's Field. Bunt drew the horse to a halt and turned to look back at them hesitantly. The traffic was a bit lighter here; the crowd split around the cart without breaking stride.

"wʌt jəɹ haɪɾɪŋ ʌndɝ jəɹ kloʊk, ɪz ɪt ɹɪli wʌt hoʊldwɪn sɛz?"

"What you're hiding under your cloak, is it really what Holdwin says?"

ɹænd wɑz ɪn ði ækt ə tɔsɪŋ ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. hi dɪd nɑɾ ivən twɪtʃ. "wʌt dʒju min?" hɪz vɔɪs wɑz stɛɾi, tu. hɪz stʌmək wɑz ə saʊɝ nɑt, bʌɾ ɪz vɔɪs wɑz stɛɾi.

Rand was in the act of tossing his saddlebags over his shoulder. He did not even twitch. "What do you mean?" His voice was steady, too. His stomach was a sour knot, but his voice was steady.

mæt staɪfəld ə jɔn wɪð wʌn hænd, bʌɾ i ʃʌv ði ʌðɝ ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt - klʌtʃɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ, ɹænd nu - ən ɪz aɪz hæɾ ə hɑɹd, hʌntəd lʊk ʌndɝ ðə skɑɹf ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd. bʌn əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət mæt, əz ɪf i nu ðəɹ wɑz ə wɛpən ɪn ðət hɪɾən hænd.

Mat stifled a yawn with one hand, but he shoved the other under his coat - clutching the dagger from Shadar Logoth, Rand knew - and his eyes had a hard, hunted look under the scarf around his head. Bunt avoided looking at Mat, as if he knew there was a weapon in that hidden hand.

"doʊn min nʌθɪŋ, aɪ səpoʊz. lʊk, naʊ, ɪf jə hɝɾ aɪ wɑz kʌmɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn, jə wɝ ðəɹ lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə hɪɹ ðə ɹɛst. wɑz aɪ æftɝ ə ɹɪwɔɹd, aɪɾ əv meɪd səm ɪkskjus tə ɡoʊ ɪn ðə ɡus ən kɹaʊn, spik tə hoʊldwɪn. oʊnli aɪ doʊn mʌtʃ laɪk hoʊldwɪn, ən aɪ doʊn laɪk ðət fɹɛn ə hɪz, nɑɾ əɾ ɔl. simz laɪk i wɑns jə tu mɔɹ ðən i wɑns . . . ɛniθɪŋ ɛls."

"Don't mean nothing, I suppose. Look, now, if you heard I was coming to Caemlyn, you were there long enough to hear the rest. Was I after a reward, I'd have made some excuse to go in the Goose and Crown, speak to Holdwin. Only I don't much like Holdwin, and I don't like that friend of his, not at all. Seems like he wants you two more than he wants . . . anything else."

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌɾ i wɑns," ɹænd sɛd. "wiv nɛvɝ sin ɪm bɪfɔɹ." ɪt maɪɾ ivən bi ðə tʃɹuθ; hi kəd nɑt tɛl wʌn feɪd fɹəm ənʌðɝ.

"I don't know what he wants," Rand said. "We've never seen him before." It might even be the truth; he could not tell one Fade from another.

"ʌ-hʌ. wɛl, laɪk aɪ seɪ, aɪ doʊnt noʊ nʌθɪŋ, ən aɪ ɡɛs aɪ doʊnt wɑn tə. ðɛɹz ɪnʌf tʃɹʌbəl ɝaʊn fəɹ ɛvɹibɑɾi wɪθaʊɾ aɪ ɡoʊ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mɔɹ."

"Uh-huh. Well, like I say, I don't know nothing, and I guess I don't want to. There's enough trouble around for everybody without I go looking for more."

mæt wɑz sloʊ ɪn ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪz θɪŋz, ən ɹænd wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ðə stʃɹit bɪfɔɹ i stɑɹɾəd klaɪmɪŋ daʊn. ɹænd weɪɾəd ɪmpeɪʃənli. mæt tɝn stɪfli fɹəm ðə kɑɹt, hʌɡɪŋ baʊ ən kwɪvɝ ən blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl tə hɪz tʃɛst, mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. hɛvi ʃædoʊz dɑɹkən ði ʌndɝsaɪdz ə hɪz aɪz.

Mat was slow in gathering his things, and Rand was already in the street before he started climbing down. Rand waited impatiently. Mat turned stiffly from the cart, hugging bow and quiver and blanketroll to his chest, muttering under his breath. Heavy shadows darkened the undersides of his eyes.

ɹændz stʌmək ɹʌmbəld, ən i ɡɹɪməst. hʌŋɡɝ kəmbaɪnd wɪð ə saʊɝ twɪstɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɡʌt meɪɾ ɪm əfɹeɪɾ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə vɑmət. mæt wɑz stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm naʊ, ɪkspɛktənli. wɪtʃ weɪ tə ɡoʊ? wʌt tə də naʊ?

Rand's stomach rumbled, and he grimaced. Hunger combined with a sour twisting in his gut made him afraid he was going to vomit. Mat was staring at him now, expectantly. Which way to go? What to do now?

bʌn lin oʊvɝ ən bɛkən ɪm kloʊsɝ. hi wɛnt, hoʊpɪŋ fəɹ ædvaɪs əbaʊt keɪɛmlɪn.

Bunt leaned over and beckoned him closer. He went, hoping for advice about Caemlyn.

"aɪd haɪd ðæt. . . ." ði oʊl fɑɹmɝ pɔzd ən lʊkt ɝaʊnd wɛɹəli. pipəl pʊʃt baɪ ɑn boʊθ saɪdz ə ðə kɑɹt, bʌɾ ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju pæsɪŋ kɝsɪz əbaʊt blɑkɪŋ ðə weɪ, noʊ wʌn peɪɾ əm ɛni ətɛnʃən. "stɑp wɛɹɪŋ ɪt," hi sɛd, "haɪɾ ɪt, sɛl ɪt. ɡɪv ɪɾ əweɪ. ðæts maɪ ædvaɪs. θɪŋ laɪk ðæts gɑnə dʒɹɔ ətɛnʃən, ən aɪ ɡɛs jə doʊnt wɑn ɛni ʌv ðæt."

"I'd hide that. . . ." The old farmer paused and looked around warily. People pushed by on both sides of the cart, but except for a few passing curses about blocking the way, no one paid them any attention. "Stop wearing it," he said, "hide it, sell it. Give it away. That's my advice. Thing like that's going to draw attention, and I guess you don't want any of that."

əbɹʌpli hi stʃɹeɪɾənd, klʌkɪŋ tə hɪz hɔɹs, ən dʒɹoʊv sloʊli ɑn daʊn ðə kɹaʊɾəd stʃɹit wɪθaʊɾ ənʌðɝ wɝɾ əɹ ə bækwɝd ɡlæns. ə wæɡən loʊɾəd wɪð bæɹəlz ɹʌmbəl təwɔɹd ðɛm. ɹænd dʒʌmpt aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ, stæɡɝd, ən wən i lʊkt əɡɛn bʌn ən ɪz kɑɹt wɝ lɔs tə saɪt.

Abruptly he straightened, clucking to his horse, and drove slowly on down the crowded street without another word or a backward glance. A wagon loaded with barrels rumbled toward them. Rand jumped out of the way, staggered, and when he looked again Bunt and his cart were lost to sight.

"wʌt də wi də naʊ?" mæt dɪmændəd. hi lɪkt ɪz lɪps, stɛɹɪŋ waɪd-aɪɾ əɾ ɔl ðə pipəl pʊʃɪŋ baɪ ən ðə bɪldɪŋz taʊɝɪŋ əz mʌtʃ əz sɪks stɔɹiz əbʌv ðə stʃɹit. "wɝ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, bʌt wʌt də wi du?" hi hæɾ ənkʌvɝɾ ɪz ɪɹz, bʌɾ ɪz hænz twɪtʃt əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə pʊɾ əm bæk. ə hʌm leɪ ɑn ðə sɪɾi, ðə loʊ, stɛɾi dʒɹoʊn ə hʌnʒɹədz ə ʃɑps wɝkɪŋ, θaʊzənz ə pipəl tɔkɪŋ. tə ɹænd ɪt wɑz laɪk biɪŋ ɪnsaɪɾ ə dʒaɪən bihaɪv, kɑnstənli bʌzɪŋ. "ivən ɪf ðeɪ ɑɹ hɪɹ, ɹænd, haʊ kəd wi faɪn əm ɪn ɔl ə ðɪs?"

"What do we do now?" Mat demanded. He licked his lips, staring wide-eyed at all the people pushing by and the buildings towering as much as six stories above the street. "We're in Caemlyn, but what do we do?" He had uncovered his ears, but his hands twitched as if he wanted to put them back. A hum lay on the city, the low, steady drone of hundreds of shops working, thousands of people talking. To Rand it was like being inside a giant beehive, constantly buzzing. "Even if they are here, Rand, how could we find them in all of this?"

"mɔɪɹeɪn wɪl faɪn ʌs," ɹænd sɛd sloʊli. ði ɪmɛnsəɾi ʌv ðə sɪɾi wɑz ə weɪɾ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz; hi wɑntəd tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ, tə haɪd fɹəm ɔl ðə pipəl ən nɔɪz. ðə vɔɪɾ ɪluɾɪd ɪm dɪspaɪt tæmz titʃɪŋz; hɪz aɪz dʒɹu ðə sɪɾi ɪndə ɪt. hi kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɪnstɛɾ ɑn wʌt wɑz ɹaɪɾ ɝaʊn hɪm, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət leɪ bɪɑnd. dʒʌs lʊkɪŋ ət ðət wʌn stʃɹit, ɪɾ ɔlmoʊst sim laɪk bɛɹlən. bɛɹlən, ðə læs pleɪs ðeɪ hæɾ ɔl θɔt ðeɪ wɝ seɪf. noʊbɑdiz seɪf ɛnimɔɹ. meɪbi ðeɪ ɑɹ ɔl dɛd. wʌt dʒju də ðɛn?

"Moiraine will find us," Rand said slowly. The immensity of the city was a weight on his shoulders; he wanted to get away, to hide from all the people and noise. The void eluded him despite Tam's teachings; his eyes drew the city into it. He concentrated instead on what was right around him, ignoring everything that lay beyond. Just looking at that one street, it almost seemed like Baerlon. Baerlon, the last place they had all thought they were safe. Nobody's safe anymore. Maybe they are all dead. What do you do then?

"ðeɪɹ əlaɪv! ɛɡwinz əlaɪv!" hi sɛd fɪɹsli. sɛvɹəl pæsɝzbi lʊkt əɾ ɪm ɑdli.

"They're alive! Egwene's alive!" he said fiercely. Several passersby looked at him oddly.

"meɪbi," mæt sɛd. "meɪbi. wʌɾ ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn dʌzn faɪn ʌs? wʌɾ ɪf noʊbɑdi dʌz bʌt ðə . . . ðə. . . ." hi ʃʌɾɝəd, əneɪbəl tə seɪ ɪt.

"Maybe," Mat said. "Maybe. What if Moiraine doesn't find us? What if nobody does but the . . . the. . . ." He shuddered, unable to say it.

"wil θɪŋk əbaʊt ðət wən ɪt hæpənz," hi toʊl mæt fɝmli. "ɪf ɪt hæpənz." ðə wɝs mɛn sikɪŋ aʊɾ ɪleɪɾə, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ðə pæləs. hi wəd ɡoʊ ɑn tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, fɝst. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪf mæt ɹɪmɛmbɝd wʌt tɑm hæd sɛɾ əbaʊt ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ - ən ðə blæk - bʌɾ i ʃʊɹli dɪd. hɪz stʌmək twɪstəɾ əɡɛn. "tɑm sɛd tə faɪn ən ɪn kɔl ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ. wɪl ɡoʊ ðəɹ fɝst."

"We'll think about that when it happens," he told Mat firmly. "If it happens." The worst meant seeking out Elaida, the Aes Sedai in the Palace. He would go on to Tar Valon, first. He did not know if Mat remembered what Thom had said about the Red Ajah - and the Black - but he surely did. His stomach twisted again. "Thom said to find an inn called The Queen's Blessing. We'll go there first."

"haʊ? wi kæn əfɔɹd wʌn mil bɪtwin ðə tu ʌv ʌs."

"How? We can't afford one meal between the two of us."

"æt list ɪts ə pleɪs tə stɑɹt. tɑm θɔt wi kəd faɪn hɛlp ðɛɹ."

"At least it's a place to start. Thom thought we could find help there."

"aɪ kænt. . . . ɹænd, ðəɹ ɛvɹiwɛɹ." mæt dʒɹɑpt ɪz aɪz tə ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz ən sim tə ʃɹɪŋk ɪn ɑn hɪmsɛlf, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə pʊl əweɪ fɹəm ðə pipəl ðət wɝ ɔl ɝaʊn ðɛm. "wɛɹɛvɝ wi ɡoʊ, ðəɹ ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn ʌs, əɹ ðəɹ weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ʌs. ðəl bi ət ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ, tu. aɪ kænt. . . . aɪ. . . . nʌθɪŋz gɑnə stɑp ə feɪd."

"I can't. . . . Rand, they're everywhere." Mat dropped his eyes to the paving stones and seemed to shrink in on himself, trying to pull away from the people that were all around them. "Wherever we go, they're right behind us, or they're waiting for us. They'll be at The Queen's Blessing, too. I can't. . . . I. . . . Nothing's going to stop a Fade."

ɹænd ɡɹæb mæts kɑlɝ ɪn ə fɪs ðəɾ i wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ hɑɹd tə kip fɹəm tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. hi niɾəd mæt. meɪbi ði ʌðɝz wɝ əlaɪv - laɪt, pliz! - bʌt ɹaɪt ðən ən ðɛɹ, ɪt wɑz dʒʌs mæt ən hɪm. ðə θɔɾ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn əloʊn. . . . hi swɑloʊd hɑɹd, teɪstɪŋ baɪl.

Rand grabbed Mat's collar in a fist that he was trying hard to keep from trembling. He needed Mat. Maybe the others were alive - Light, please! - but right then and there, it was just Mat and him. The thought of going on alone. . . . He swallowed hard, tasting bile.

hi lʊkt ɝaʊn kwɪkli. noʊ wʌn sim tə hæv hɝd mæt mɛnʃən ðə feɪd; ðə kɹaʊd pɹɛs pæs lɔst ɪn ɪts oʊn wɝiz. hi pʊɾ ɪz feɪs kloʊs tə mæts. "wiv meɪɾ ɪt ðɪs fɑɹ, hævənt wi?" hi æskt ɪn ə hɔɹs wɪspɝ. "ðeɪ hævən kɑɾ əs jɛt. wi kən meɪk ɪɾ ɔl ðə weɪ, ɪf wi dʒʌs doʊn kwɪt. aɪ woʊn dʒʌs kwɪɾ ən weɪt fəɹ əm laɪk ə ʃip fəɹ slɔɾɝ. aɪ woʊnt! wɛl? ɑɹ jə gɑnə stæn hɪɹ tɪl jə stɑɹv tə dɛθ? əɹ əntɪl ðeɪ kʌm pɪk jə ʌp ɪn ə sæk?"

He looked around quickly. No one seemed to have heard Mat mention the Fade; the crowd pressed past lost in its own worries. He put his face close to Mat's. "We've made it this far, haven't we?" he asked in a hoarse whisper. "They haven't caught us yet. We can make it all the way, if we just don't quit. I won't just quit and wait for them like a sheep for slaughter. I won't! Well? Are you going to stand here till you starve to death? Or until they come pick you up in a sack?"

hi lɛt ɡoʊ ʌv mæt ən tɝn əweɪ. hɪz fɪŋɡɝneɪlz dʌɡ ɪndə hɪz pɑmz, bʌɾ ɪz hænz stɪl tʃɹɛmbəld. sʌɾənli mæt wɑz wɔkɪŋ əlɔŋsaɪd hɪm, hɪz aɪz stɪl daʊn, ən ɹænd lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ.

He let go of Mat and turned away. His fingernails dug into his palms, but his hands still trembled. Suddenly Mat was walking alongside him, his eyes still down, and Rand let out a long breath.

"aɪm sɑɹi, ɹænd," mæt mʌmbəld.

"I'm sorry, Rand," Mat mumbled.

"fɝɡɛɾ ɪt," ɹænd sɛd.

"Forget it," Rand said.

mæt bɛɹli lʊkt ʌp ɪnʌf tə kip fɹəm wɔkɪŋ ɪndə pipəl waɪl ðə wɝdz pɔɹɾ aʊɾ ɪn ə laɪfləs vɔɪs. "aɪ kæn stɑp θɪŋkɪŋ əl nɛvɝ si hoʊm əɡɛn. aɪ wɑnə ɡoʊ hoʊm. læf ɪf jə wɑnt; aɪ doʊn kɛɹ. wʌɾ aɪ wʊdnt ɡɪv tə hæv maɪ mʌðɝ blɛsɪŋ mi aʊt fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ ɹaɪt naʊ. ɪts laɪk weɪts ɑn maɪ bɹeɪn; hɑt weɪts. stʃɹeɪnʒɝz ɔl ɝaʊnd, ən noʊ weɪ tə tɛl u tə tʃɹʌst, ɪf aɪ kən tʃɹʌst ɛnibəɾi. laɪt, ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɪz soʊ fɑɹ əweɪ ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl bi ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə wɝld. wɝ əloʊn, ən wɪl nɛvɝ ɡɛt hoʊm. wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ tə daɪ, ɹænd."

Mat barely looked up enough to keep from walking into people while the words poured out in a lifeless voice. "I can't stop thinking I'll never see home again. I want to go home. Laugh if you want; I don't care. What I wouldn't give to have my mother blessing me out for something right now. It's like weights on my brain; hot weights. Strangers all around, and no way to tell who to trust, if I can trust anybody. Light, the Two Rivers is so far away it might as well be on the other side of the world. We're alone, and we'll never get home. We're going to die, Rand."

"nɑt jɛt, wi woʊnt," ɹænd ɹitɔɹɾɪd. "ɛvɹibɑɾi daɪz. ðə wil tɝnz. aɪm nɑt gɑnə kɝl ʌp ən weɪt fəɹ ɪt tə hæpən, ðoʊ."

"Not yet, we won't," Rand retorted. "Everybody dies. The Wheel turns. I'm not going to curl up and wait for it to happen, though."

"ju saʊn laɪk mæstɝ ælvɪɹ," mæt ɡɹʌmbəld, bʌɾ ɪz vɔɪs hæɾ ə lɪɾəl spɪɹəɾ ɪn ɪt.

"You sound like Master al'Vere," Mat grumbled, but his voice had a little spirit in it.

"ɡʊd," ɹænd sɛd. "ɡʊd." laɪt, lɛt ði ʌðɝz bi ɔl ɹaɪt. pliz doʊn lɛɾ əs bi əloʊn.

"Good," Rand said. "Good." Light, let the others be all right. Please don't let us be alone.

hi bɪɡæn æskɪŋ dɝɛkʃənz tə ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ. ðə ɹɪspɑnsɪz vɛɹid waɪdli, ə kɝs fəɹ ɔl ðoʊz u dɪd nɑt steɪ wɛɹ ðeɪ bɪlɔŋd əɹ ə ʃɹʌɡ ən ə blæŋk lʊk biɪŋ ðə moʊs kɑmən. səm stɔkt ɑn baɪ wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə ɡlæns, ɪf ðæt.

He began asking directions to The Queen's Blessing. The responses varied widely, a curse for all those who did not stay where they belonged or a shrug and a blank look being the most common. Some stalked on by with no more than a glance, if that.

ə bɹɔd-feɪs mæn, nɪɹli əz bɪɡ əz pɛɹɪn, kɑkt ɪz hɛɾ ən sɛd, "ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ, ɛ? jə kʌntʃɹi bɔɪz kwinz mɛn?" hi wɔɹ ə waɪt kɑkeɪɾ ɑn ɪz waɪd-bɹɪm hæt, ən ə waɪɾ ɑɹmbæn ɑn ɪz lɔŋ koʊt. "wɛl, juv kʌm tu leɪt."

A broad-faced man, nearly as big as Perrin, cocked his head and said, "The Queen's Blessing, eh? You country boys Queen's men?" He wore a white cockade on his wide-brimmed hat, and a white armband on his long coat. "Well, you've come too late."

hi wɛn ɔf ɹɔɹɪŋ wɪð læftɝ, livɪŋ ɹænd ən mæt tə stɛɹ ət wʌn ənʌðɝ ɪn pʌzəlmənt. ɹænd ʃɹʌɡd; ðəɹ wɝ plɛnti ʌv ɑd foʊk ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, pipəl laɪk i hæd nɛvɝ sin bɪfɔɹ.

He went off roaring with laughter, leaving Rand and Mat to stare at one another in puzzlement. Rand shrugged; there were plenty of odd folk in Caemlyn, people like he had never seen before.

səm ə ðɛm stʊɾ aʊɾ ɪn ðə kɹaʊd, skɪnz tu dɑɹk əɹ tu peɪl, koʊts ə stʃɹeɪnʒ kʌɾ əɹ bɹaɪt kʌlɝz, hæts wɪð pɔɪntəd piks əɹ lɔŋ fɛðɝz. ðəɹ wɝ wɪmən wɪð veɪlz əkɹɔs ðɛɹ feɪsəz, wɪmən ɪn stɪf dʒɹɛsəz əz waɪɾ əz ðə wɛɹɝ wɑz tɔl, wɪmən ɪn dʒɹɛsəz ðət lɛf mɔɹ skɪn bɛɹ ðən ɛni tɑvɝmeɪɾ i hæd sin. əkeɪʒənəli ə kæɹɪdʒ, ɔl vɪvəd peɪn ən ɡɪlt, skwiz θɹu ðə θɹɔŋ stʃɹits bɪhaɪn ə fɔɹ-ɔɹ sɪks-hɔɹs tim wɪð plumz ɑn ðɛɹ hɑɹnəs. sɪdæn tʃɛɹz wɝ ɛvɹiwɛɹ, ðə pəlmən pʊʃɪŋ əlɔŋ wɪð nɛvɝ ə kɛɹ fəɹ u ðeɪ ʃʌvd əsaɪd.

Some of them stood out in the crowd, skins too dark or too pale, coats of strange cut or bright colors, hats with pointed peaks or long feathers. There were women with veils across their faces, women in stiff dresses as wide as the wearer was tall, women in dresses that left more skin bare than any tavernmaid he had seen. Occasionally a carriage, all vivid paint and gilt, squeezed through the thronged streets behind a four-or six-horse team with plumes on their harness. Sedan chairs were everywhere, the polemen pushing along with never a care for who they shoved aside.

ɹænd sɔ wʌn faɪt stɑɹt ðət weɪ, ə bɹɔlɪŋ hip ə mɛn swɪŋɪŋ ðɛɹ fɪsts waɪl ə peɪl-skɪn mæn ɪn ə ɹɛd-stʃɹaɪp koʊt klaɪmd aʊɾ ə ðə sɪdæn tʃɛɹ laɪɪŋ ɑn ɪts saɪd. tu ɹʌfli dʒɹɛs mɛn, hu sim tə hæv bɪn dʒʌs pæsɪŋ baɪ ʌp tɪl ðɛn, dʒʌmpt ɑn ɪm bɪfɔɹ i wɑz klɪɹ. ðə kɹaʊd ðət hæd stɑp tə wɑtʃ bɪɡæn tə tɝn ʌɡli, mʌɾɝɪŋ ən ʃeɪkɪŋ fɪsts. ɹænd pʊld ət mæts sliv ən hɝiɾ ɑn. mæt niɾəd noʊ sɛkən ɝdʒɪŋ. ðə ɹɔɹ ʌv ə smɔl ɹaɪət fɑloʊɾ əm daʊn ðə stʃɹit.

Rand saw one fight start that way, a brawling heap of men swinging their fists while a pale-skinned man in a red-striped coat climbed out of the sedan chair lying on its side. Two roughly dressed men, who seemed to have been just passing by up till then, jumped on him before he was clear. The crowd that had stopped to watch began to turn ugly, muttering and shaking fists. Rand pulled at Mat's sleeve and hurried on. Mat needed no second urging. The roar of a small riot followed them down the street.

sɛvɹəl taɪmz mɛn əpɹoʊtʃt ðə tu ʌv əm ɪnstɛɾ ə ði ʌðɝ weɪ ɝaʊnd. ðɛɹ dʌsti kloʊðz mɑɹkt əm əz nukʌmɝz, ən sim tə æk laɪk ə mæɡnəɾ ɑn səm taɪps. fɝɾɪv fɛloʊz u ɔfɝd ɹɛlɪks ə lɑɡən fəɹ seɪl wɪð dɑɹɾɪŋ aɪz ən fit sɛt tə ɹʌn. ɹænd kælkjəleɪɾəd i wɑz ɔfɝɾ ɪnʌf skɹæps ə ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡənz kloʊk ən fɹæɡməns ə hɪz sɔɹd tə meɪk tu sɔɹdz ən hæf ə dʌzən kloʊks. mæts feɪs bɹaɪɾənd wɪð ɪntʃɹəst, ðə fɝs taɪm ət list, bʌt ɹænd ɡeɪv əm ɔl ə kɝt noʊ, ən ðeɪ tʊk ɪt wɪð ə bɑb ə ðə hɛɾ ən ə kwɪk, "laɪɾ ɪlumin ðə kwin, ɡʊd mæstɝ," ən vænɪʃt. moʊst ə ðə ʃɑps hæd pleɪts ən kʌps peɪntəd wɪð fænsɪfəl sinz pɝpɔɹɾɪŋ tə ʃoʊ ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən biɪŋ dɪspleɪd bɪfɔɹ ðə kwin ɪn tʃeɪnz. ən ðəɹ wɝ waɪtkloʊks ɪn ðə stʃɹits. itʃ wɔkt ɪn ən oʊpən speɪs ðət muvd wɪð hɪm, dʒʌst əz ɪn bɛɹlən.

Several times men approached the two of them instead of the other way around. Their dusty clothes marked them as newcomers, and seemed to act like a magnet on some types. Furtive fellows who offered relics of Logain for sale with darting eyes and feet set to run. Rand calculated he was offered enough scraps of the false Dragon's cloak and fragments of his sword to make two swords and half a dozen cloaks. Mat's face brightened with interest, the first time at least, but Rand gave them all a curt no, and they took it with a bob of the head and a quick, "Light illumine the Queen, good master," and vanished. Most of the shops had plates and cups painted with fanciful scenes purporting to show the false Dragon being displayed before the Queen in chains. And there were Whitecloaks in the streets. Each walked in an open space that moved with him, just as in Baerlon.

steɪɪŋ ənnoʊɾɪst wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɹænd θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ə ɡɹeɪt dil. hi kɛpt ɪz kloʊk oʊvɝ ɪz sɔɹd, bʌt ðət wəd nɑt bi ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ vɛɹi lɔŋ. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ sʌmwʌn wəd wʌndɝ wʌɾ i wɑz haɪɾɪŋ. hi wəd nɑt - kəd nɑt - teɪk bʌns ædvaɪs tə stɑp wɛɹɪŋ ɪt, nɑɾ ɪz lɪŋk tə tæm. tə hɪz fɑðɝ.

Staying unnoticed was something Rand thought about a great deal. He kept his cloak over his sword, but that would not be good enough for very long. Sooner or later someone would wonder what he was hiding. He would not - could not - take Bunt's advice to stop wearing it, not his link to Tam. To his father.

mɛni ʌðɝz əmʌŋ ðə θɹɔŋ wɔɹ sɔɹdz, bʌt nʌn wɪð ðə hɛɹənmɑɹk tə pʊl ði aɪ. ɔl ðə keɪɛmlɪn mɛn, ðoʊ, ən səm ə ðə stʃɹeɪnʒɝz, hæd ðɛɹ sɔɹdz waʊn ɪn stʃɹɪps ə klɔθ, ʃiθ ən hɪlt, ɹɛd baʊnd wɪð waɪt kɔɹd, əɹ waɪt baʊnd wɪð ɹɛd. ə hʌnʒɹəd hɛɹən-mɑɹks kəd bi hɪɾən ʌndɝ ðoʊz ɹæpɪŋz ən noʊ wʌn wəd si. bɪsaɪdz, fɑloʊɪŋ loʊkəl fæʃən wəd meɪk əm sim tə fɪɾ ɪn mɔɹ.

Many others among the throng wore swords, but none with the heronmark to pull the eye. All the Caemlyn men, though, and some of the strangers, had their swords wound in strips of cloth, sheath and hilt, red bound with white cord, or white bound with red. A hundred heron-marks could be hidden under those wrappings and no one would see. Besides, following local fashion would make them seem to fit in more.

ə ɡʊd mɛni ʃɑps wɝ fɹʌntɪd wɪð teɪbəlz dɪspleɪɪŋ ðə klɔθ ən kɔɹd, ən ɹænd stɑpt ət wʌn. ðə ɹɛd klɔθ wɑz tʃipɝ ðən ðə waɪt, ðoʊ hi kəd si noʊ dɪfɝəns əpɑɹt fɹəm ðə kʌlɝ, soʊ hi bɑt ðəɾ ən ðə waɪt kɔɹd tə ɡoʊ wɪð ɪt, dɪspaɪt mæts kəmpleɪns əbaʊt haʊ lɪɾəl mʌni ðeɪ hæd lɛft. ðə taɪt-lɪpt ʃɑpkipɝ aɪɾ əm ʌp ən daʊn wɪð ə twɪs tə hɪz maʊθ waɪl i tʊk ɹændz kɑpɝz, ən kɝst əm wən ɹænd æsk fəɹ ə pleɪs ɪnsaɪd tə ɹæp ɪz sɔɹd.

A good many shops were fronted with tables displaying the cloth and cord, and Rand stopped at one. The red cloth was cheaper than the white, though he could see no difference apart from the color, so he bought that and the white cord to go with it, despite Mat's complaints about how little money they had left. The tight-lipped shopkeeper eyed them up and down with a twist to his mouth while he took Rand's coppers, and cursed them when Rand asked for a place inside to wrap his sword.

"wi dɪdn kʌm tə si lɑɡən," ɹænd sɛd peɪʃənli. "wi dʒʌs keɪm tə si keɪɛmlɪn." hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd bʌnt, ən æɾəd, "ðə ɡɹændəst sɪɾi ɪn ðə wɝld." ðə ʃɑpkipɝz ɡɹɪmɑs ɹɪmeɪn ɪn pleɪs. "ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ɡʊd kwin mɔɹɡeɪs," ɹænd sɛd hoʊpfəli.

"We didn't come to see Logain," Rand said patiently. "We just came to see Caemlyn." He remembered Bunt, and added, "The grandest city in the world." The shopkeeper's grimace remained in place. "The Light illumine good Queen Morgase," Rand said hopefully.

"ju meɪk ɛni tʃɹʌbəl," ðə mæn sɛd saʊɝli, "æn ðɛɹz ə hʌnʒɹəd mɛn ɪn saʊn ə maɪ vɔɪs wɪl teɪk kɛɹ ə jə ivən ɪf ðə ɡɑɹdz woʊnt." hi pɔz tə spɪt, dʒʌs mɪsɪŋ ɹændz fʊt. "ɡɛɾ ɑn əbaʊt jəɹ fɪlθi bɪznəs."

"You make any trouble," the man said sourly, "and there's a hundred men in sound of my voice will take care of you even if the Guards won't." He paused to spit, just missing Rand's foot. "Get on about your filthy business."

ɹænd nɑɾəd əz ɪf ðə mæn hæd bɪɾ ɪm ə tʃɪɹfəl fɛɹwɛl, ən pʊl mæt əweɪ. mæt kɛp lʊkɪŋ bæk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ təwɔɹd ðə ʃɑp, ɡɹoʊlɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf, əntɪl ɹænd tʌɡd ɪm ɪndə ən ɛmpti æliweɪ. wɪð ðɛɹ bæks tə ðə stʃɹit noʊ pæsɝbaɪ kəd si wʌt ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ. ɹænd pʊld ɔf ðə sɔɹd bɛlt ən sɛt tə ɹæpɪŋ ðə ʃiθ ən hɪlt.

Rand nodded as if the man had bid him a cheerful farewell, and pulled Mat away. Mat kept looking back over his shoulder toward the shop, growling to himself, until Rand tugged him into an empty alleyway. With their backs to the street no passerby could see what they were doing. Rand pulled off the sword belt and set to wrapping the sheath and hilt.

"aɪl bɛɾ i tʃɑɹdʒ jə dʌbəl fəɹ ðət blʌɾi klɔθ," mæt sɛd. "tʃɹɪpəl."

"I'll bet he charged you double for that bloody cloth," Mat said. "Triple."

ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz izi əz ɪt lʊkt, fæsənɪŋ ðə stʃɹɪps ə klɔθ ən ðə kɔɹd soʊ ðə hoʊl θɪŋ wəd nɑt fɔl ɔf.

It was not as easy as it looked, fastening the strips of cloth and the cord so the whole thing would not fall off.

"ðeɪl ɔl bi tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə tʃiɾ ʌs, ɹænd. ðeɪ θɪŋk wiv kʌm tə si ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən, laɪk ɛvɹibɑɾi ɛls. wɪl bi lʌki ɪf sʌmbɑɾi dʌzn hɪɾ əs ɑn ðə hɛd waɪl wi slip. ðɪs ɪz noʊ pleɪs tə bi. ðəɹ ɑɹ tu mɛni pipəl. lɛts liv fəɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn naʊ. əɹ saʊθ, tə ɪljən. aɪ wʊdn maɪn siɪŋ əm ɡæðɝ fəɹ ðə hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn. ɪf wi kænt ɡoʊ hoʊm, lɛts dʒʌst ɡoʊ."

"They'll all be trying to cheat us, Rand. They think we've come to see the false Dragon, like everybody else. We'll be lucky if somebody doesn't hit us on the head while we sleep. This is no place to be. There are too many people. Let's leave for Tar Valon now. Or south, to Illian. I wouldn't mind seeing them gather for the Hunt of the Horn. If we can't go home, let's just go."

"aɪm steɪɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd. "ɪf ðəɹ nɑt hɪɹ ɔlɹɛɾi, ðəl kʌm hɪɹ sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ, lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ʌs."

"I'm staying," Rand said. "If they're not here already, they'll come here sooner or later, looking for us."

hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf i hæd ðə ɹæpɪŋz dʌn ðə weɪ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls dɪd, bʌt ðə hɛɹənz ɑn skæbɝɾ ən hɪlt wɝ hɪɾən ən i θɔɾ ɪt wɑz sɪkjʊɹ. əz i wɛn bæk aʊɾ ɑn ðə stʃɹit, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðəɾ i hæd wʌn lɛs θɪŋ tə wɝi əbaʊt kɑzɪŋ tʃɹʌbəl. mæt tʃɹeɪld əlɔŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪm əz ɹɪlʌktənli əz ɪf i wɝ biɪŋ pʊld ɑn ə liʃ.

He was not sure if he had the wrappings done the way everyone else did, but the herons on scabbard and hilt were hidden and he thought it was secure. As he went back out on the street, he was sure that he had one less thing to worry about causing trouble. Mat trailed along beside him as reluctantly as if he were being pulled on a leash.

bɪt baɪ bɪt ɹænd dɪd ɡɛt ðə dɝɛkʃənz i wɑntəd. ət fɝs ðeɪ wɝ veɪɡ, ɑn ði ɔɹɾɝ ʌv "sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən" ən "oʊvɝ ðət weɪ." ðə nɪɹɝ ðeɪ keɪm, ðoʊ, ðə klɪɹɝ ði ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz, əntɪl ət læs ðeɪ stʊd bɪfɔɹ ə bɹɔd stoʊn bɪldɪŋ wɪð ə saɪn oʊvɝ ðə dɔɹ kɹikɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd. ə mæn nilɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ə wʊmən wɪð ɹɛd-ɡoʊl hɛɹ ən ə kɹaʊn, wʌn ə hɝ hænz ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ɪz baʊd hɛd. ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ.

Bit by bit Rand did get the directions he wanted. At first they were vague, on the order of "somewhere in that direction" and "over that way." The nearer they came, though, the clearer the instructions, until at last they stood before a broad stone building with a sign over the door creaking in the wind. A man kneeling before a woman with red-gold hair and a crown, one of her hands resting on his bowed head. The Queen's Blessing.

"ɑɹ jə ʃʊɹ əbaʊt ðɪs?" mæt æskt.

"Are you sure about this?" Mat asked.

"ʌv kɔɹs," ɹænd sɛd. hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən pʊʃt oʊpən ðə dɔɹ.

"Of course," Rand said. He took a deep breath and pushed open the door.

ðə kɑmən ɹum wɑz lɑɹdʒ ən pænəld wɪð dɑɹk wʊd, ən faɪɝz ɑn tu hɑɹθs wɔɹmd ɪt. ə sɝvɪŋ meɪd wɑz swipɪŋ ðə flɔɹ, ðoʊ ɪt wɑz klin, ən ənʌðɝ wɑz pɑlɪʃɪŋ kændəlstɪks ɪn ðə kɔɹnɝ. itʃ smaɪld ət ðə tu nukʌmɝz bɪfɔɹ ɡoʊɪŋ bæk tə hɝ wɝk.

The common room was large and paneled with dark wood, and fires on two hearths warmed it. A serving maid was sweeping the floor, though it was clean, and another was polishing candlesticks in the corner. Each smiled at the two newcomers before going back to her work.

oʊnli ə fju teɪbəlz hæd pipəl ət ðɛm, bʌɾ ə dʌzən mɛn wɑz ə kɹaʊd fəɹ soʊ ɝli ɪn ðə deɪ, ən ɪf nʌn lʊkt ɪɡzækli hæpi tə si hɪm ən mæt, ət lis ðeɪ lʊkt klin ən soʊbɝ. ðə smɛlz ə ɹoʊstɪŋ bif ən beɪkɪŋ bɹɛd dʒɹɪftəd fɹəm ðə kɪtʃən, meɪkɪŋ ɹændz maʊθ wɔɾɝ.

Only a few tables had people at them, but a dozen men was a crowd for so early in the day, and if none looked exactly happy to see him and Mat, at least they looked clean and sober. The smells of roasting beef and baking bread drifted from the kitchen, making Rand's mouth water.

ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz fæt, hi wɑz pliz tə si, ə pɪŋk-feɪs mæn ɪn ə stɑɹtʃt waɪɾ eɪpɹən, wɪð ɡɹeɪɪŋ hɛɹ koʊm bæk oʊvɝ ə bɔl spɑt ðəɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt kwaɪt kʌvɝ. hɪz ʃɑɹp aɪ tʊk əm ɪn fɹəm hɛd tə toʊ, dʌsti kloʊðz ən bʌndəlz ən wɔɹn buts, bʌɾ i hæɾ ə ɹɛɾi, plɛzən smaɪl, tu. bɑzəl ɡɪl wɑz ɪz neɪm.

The innkeeper was fat, he was pleased to see, a pink-faced man in a starched white apron, with graying hair combed back over a bald spot that it did not quite cover. His sharp eye took them in from head to toe, dusty clothes and bundles and worn boots, but he had a ready, pleasant smile, too. Basel Gill was his name.

"mæstɝ ɡɪl," ɹænd sɛd, "ə fɹɛn ʌv aʊɝz toʊld əs tə kʌm hɪɹ. tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn. hi - " ði ɪnkipɝz smaɪl slɪpt. ɹænd lʊkt ət mæt, bʌɾ i wɑz tu bɪzi snɪfɪŋ ði ɝoʊməz kʌmɪŋ fɹəm ðə kɪtʃən tə noʊɾəs ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. "ɪz sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔŋ? jə də noʊ hɪm?"

"Master Gill," Rand said, "a friend of ours told us to come here. Thom Merrilin. He - " The innkeeper's smile slipped. Rand looked at Mat, but he was too busy sniffing the aromas coming from the kitchen to notice anything else. "Is something wrong? You do know him?"

"aɪ noʊ hɪm," ɡɪl sɛd kɝtli. hi simd mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ðə flut keɪs ət ɹændz saɪd naʊ, ðən ɪn ɛniθɪŋ ɛls. "kʌm wɪð mi." hi dʒɝkt ɪz hɛd təwɔɹd ðə bæk. ɹænd ɡeɪv mæt ə dʒɝk tə ɡɛɾ ɪm stɑɹɾəd, ðən fɑloʊd, wʌndɝɪŋ wʌt wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn.

"I know him," Gill said curtly. He seemed more interested in the flute case at Rand's side now, than in anything else. "Come with me." He jerked his head toward the back. Rand gave Mat a jerk to get him started, then followed, wondering what was going on.

ɪn ðə kɪtʃən, mæstɝ ɡɪl pɔz tə spik tə ðə kʊk, ə ɹaʊnd wʊmən wɪð əɹ hɛɹ ɪn ə bʌn ət ðə bæk ə hɝ hɛɾ u ɔlmoʊs mætʃt ði ɪnkipɝ paʊn fəɹ paʊnd. ʃi kɛp stɝɪŋ əɹ pɑts waɪl mæstɝ ɡɪl tɔkt. ðə smɛlz wɝ soʊ ɡʊd - tu deɪz' hʌŋɡɝ meɪɾ ə faɪn sɔs fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ, bʌt ðɪs smɛld əz ɡʊɾ əz mɪstʃɹəs ælvɪɹz kɪtʃən - ðət ɹændz stʌmək ɡɹaʊld. mæt wɑz linɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə pɑts, noʊz fɝst. ɹænd nʌdʒ hɪm; mæt heɪstəli waɪpt ɪz tʃɪn wɛɹ i hæd bɪɡʌn dʒɹulɪŋ.

In the kitchen, Master Gill paused to speak to the cook, a round woman with her hair in a bun at the back of her head who almost matched the innkeeper pound for pound. She kept stirring her pots while Master Gill talked. The smells were so good - two days' hunger made a fine sauce for anything, but this smelled as good as Mistress al'Vere's kitchen - that Rand's stomach growled. Mat was leaning toward the pots, nose first. Rand nudged him; Mat hastily wiped his chin where he had begun drooling.

ðən ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz hɝiɪŋ əm aʊt ðə bæk dɔɹ. ɪn ðə steɪbliɑɹɾ i lʊkt ɝaʊn tə meɪk ʃʊɹ noʊ wʌn wɑz kloʊs, ðən ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn ðɛm. ɑn ɹænd. "wʌts ɪn ðə keɪs, læd?"

Then the innkeeper was hurrying them out the back door. In the stableyard he looked around to make sure no one was close, then rounded on them. On Rand. "What's in the case, lad?"

"tɑmz flut," ɹænd sɛd sloʊli. hi oʊpən ðə keɪs, əz ɪf ʃoʊɪŋ ðə ɡoʊld-ænd-sɪlvɝ-tʃeɪs flut wəd hɛlp. mæts hæn kɹɛpt ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt.

"Thom's flute," Rand said slowly. He opened the case, as if showing the gold-and-silver-chased flute would help. Mat's hand crept under his coat.

mæstɝ ɡɪl dɪd nɑt teɪk ɪz aɪz ɔf ɹænd. "aɪ, aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɪt. aɪ sɔ hɪm pleɪ ɪɾ ɔfən ɪnʌf, ən ðɛɹz nɑt laɪkli tu laɪk ðəɾ aʊtsaɪɾ ə ɹɔɪəl kɔɹt." ðə plɛzən smaɪlz wɝ ɡɔn, ən ɪz ʃɑɹp aɪz wɝ sʌɾənli əz ʃɑɹp əz ə naɪf. "haʊ dɪd jə kʌm baɪ ɪt? tɑm wəd pɑɹt wɪð ɪz ɑɹm əz sun əz ðət flut."

Master Gill did not take his eyes off Rand. "Aye, I recognize it. I saw him play it often enough, and there's not likely two like that outside a royal court." The pleasant smiles were gone, and his sharp eyes were suddenly as sharp as a knife. "How did you come by it? Thom would part with his arm as soon as that flute."

"hi ɡeɪv ɪt tə mi." ɹænd tʊk tɑmz bʌndəl kloʊk fɹəm ɪz bæk ən sɛɾ ɪɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ənfoʊldɪŋ ɪnʌf tə ʃoʊ ðə kʌlɝd pætʃəz, əz wɛl əz ði ɛn ə ðə hɑɹp keɪs. "tɑmz dɛd, mæstɝ ɡɪl. ɪf i wɑz jəɹ fɹɛnd, aɪm sɑɹi. hi wɑz maɪn, tu."

"He gave it to me." Rand took Thom's bundled cloak from his back and set it on the ground, unfolding enough to show the colored patches, as well as the end of the harp case. "Thom's dead, Master Gill. If he was your friend, I'm sorry. He was mine, too."

"dɛd, jə seɪ. haʊ?"

"Dead, you say. How?"

"ə . . . ə mæn tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl ʌs. tɑm pʊʃt ðɪs ət mi ən toʊld əs tə ɹʌn." ðə pætʃəz flʌɾɝd ɪn ðə wɪn laɪk bʌɾɝflaɪz. ɹændz θɹoʊt kɑt; hi foʊldəd ðə kloʊk kɛɹfəli bæk ʌp əɡɛn. "wiɾ əv bɪn kɪld ɪf ɪt hædn bɪn fəɹ hɪm. wi wɝ ɑn əɹ weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn təɡɛðɝ. hi toʊld əs tə kʌm hɪɹ, tə jəɹ ɪn."

"A . . . a man tried to kill us. Thom pushed this at me and told us to run." The patches fluttered in the wind like butterflies. Rand's throat caught; he folded the cloak carefully back up again. "We'd have been killed if it hadn't been for him. We were on our way to Caemlyn together. He told us to come here, to your inn."

"aɪl bɪliv hiz dɛd," ði ɪnkipɝ sɛd sloʊli, "wɛn aɪ si hɪz kɔɹps." hi nʌdʒ ðə bʌndəl kloʊk wɪð ɪz toʊ ən klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt ɹʌfli. "neɪ, neɪ, aɪ bɪliv jə sɔ wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz jə sɔ; aɪ dʒʌs doʊn bɪliv hiz dɛd. hiz ə hɑɹɾɝ mæn tə kɪl ðən jə maɪt bɪliv, ɪz oʊl tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn."

"I'll believe he's dead," the innkeeper said slowly, "when I see his corpse." He nudged the bundled cloak with his toe and cleared his throat roughly. "Nay, nay, I believe you saw Whatever it was you saw; I just don't believe he's dead. He's a harder man to kill than you might believe, is old Thom Merrilin."

ɹænd pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn mæts ʃoʊldɝ. "ɪts ɔl ɹaɪt, mæt. hiz ə fɹɛnd."

Rand put a hand on Mat's shoulder. "It's all right, Mat. He's a friend."

mæstɝ ɡɪl ɡlænst ət mæt, ən saɪd. "aɪ səpoʊz aɪm ət ðæt."

Master Gill glanced at Mat, and sighed. "I suppose I am at that."

mæt stʃɹeɪɾənd ʌp sloʊli, foʊldɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz oʊvɝ ɪz tʃɛst. hi wɑz stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ ði ɪnkipɝ wɛɹəli, ðoʊ, ən ə mʌsəl ɪn ɪz tʃik twɪtʃt.

Mat straightened up slowly, folding his arms over his chest. He was still watching the innkeeper warily, though, and a muscle in his cheek twitched.

"kʌmɪŋ tə keɪɛmlɪn, jə seɪ?" ði ɪnkipɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ðɪs ɪz ðə læs pleɪs ɑn ɝθ aɪɾ ɪkspɛk tɑm tə kʌm, ɛksɛptɪŋ meɪbi ɪt wɑz tɑɹ vəlɑn." hi weɪɾəd fəɹ ə steɪbəlmən tə pæs, liɾɪŋ ə hɔɹs, ən ivən ðən i loʊɝɾ ɪz vɔɪs. "juv tʃɹʌbəl wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, aɪ teɪk ɪt."

"Coming to Caemlyn, you say?" The innkeeper shook his head. "This is the last place on earth I'd expect Thom to come, excepting maybe it was Tar Valon." He waited for a stableman to pass, leading a horse, and even then he lowered his voice. "You've trouble with the Aes Sedai, I take it."

"jɛs," mæt ɡɹʌmbəld ət ðə seɪm taɪm ðət ɹænd sɛd, "wʌt meɪks jə θɪŋk ðæt?"

"Yes," Mat grumbled at the same time that Rand said, "What makes you think that?"

mæstɝ ɡɪl tʃʌkəl dʒɹaɪli. "aɪ noʊ ðə mæn, ðæts wʌt. hid dʒʌmp ɪndə ðət kaɪndə tʃɹʌbəl, ɪspɛʃli tə hɛlp ə kʌpəl ə lædz əbaʊt ði eɪdʒ ə ju. . . ." ðə ɹɛmənɪsəns ɪn ɪz aɪz flɪkɝɾ aʊt, ən i stʊɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt wɪð ə tʃɑɹi lʊk. "naʊ . . . ɑ . . . aɪm nɑt meɪkɪŋ ɛni ækjəzeɪʃənz, maɪnd, bʌt . . . ɑ . . . aɪ teɪk ɪt niðɝ ə jə kən . . . ɑ . . . wʌɾ aɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ əɾ ɪz . . . ɑ . . . wʌɾ ɪɡzækli ɪz ðə neɪtʃɝ ə jəɹ tʃɹʌbəl wɪð tɑɹ vəlɑn, ɪf jə doʊn maɪn maɪ æskɪŋ?"

Master Gill chuckled dryly. "I know the man, that's what. He'd jump into that kind of trouble, especially to help a couple of lads about the age of you. . . ." The reminiscence in his eyes flickered out, and he stood up straight with a chary look. "Now . . . ah . . . I'm not making any accusations, mind, but . . . ah . . . I take it neither of you can . . . ah . . . what I'm getting at is . . . ah . . . what exactly is the nature of your trouble with Tar Valon, if you don't mind my asking?"

ɹændz skɪn pɹɪkəld əz i ɹilaɪzd wʌt ðə mæn wɑz sədʒɛstɪŋ. ðə wʌn paʊɝ. "noʊ, noʊ, nʌθɪŋ laɪk ðæt. aɪ swɛɹ. ðəɹ wɑz ivən ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hɛlpɪŋ ʌs. mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz. . . ." hi bɪɾ ɪz tʌŋ, bʌt ði ɪnkipɝz ɪkspɹɛʃən nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd.

Rand's skin prickled as he realized what the man was suggesting. The One Power. "No, no, nothing like that. I swear. There was even an Aes Sedai helping us. Moiraine was. . . ." He bit his tongue, but the innkeeper's expression never changed.

"ɡlæd tə hɪɹ ɪt. nɑt ðəɾ aɪv ɔl ðət mʌtʃ lʌv fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt bɛɾɝ əm ðən . . . ðəɾ ʌðɝ θɪŋ." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sloʊli. "tu mʌtʃ tɔk ə ðət kaɪndə θɪŋ, wɪð lɑɡən biɪŋ bɹɔt hɪɹ. noʊ əfɛns mɛnt, jə ʌndɝstænd, bʌt . . . wɛl, aɪ hæd tə noʊ, dɪdn aɪ?"

"Glad to hear it. Not that I've all that much love for Aes Sedai, but better them than . . . that other thing." He shook his head slowly. "Too much talk of that kind of thing, with Logain being brought here. No offense meant, you understand, but . . . well, I had to know, didn't I?"

"noʊ əfɛns," ɹænd sɛd. mæts mɝmɝ cʊɾə bɪn ɛniθɪŋ, bʌt ði ɪnkipɝ əpɪɹd tə teɪk ɪt fəɹ ðə seɪm əz ɹænd hæd sɛd.

"No offense," Rand said. Mat's murmur could have been anything, but the innkeeper appeared to take it for the same as Rand had said.

"ju tu lʊk ðə ɹaɪt sɔɹt, ən aɪ də bɪliv jə wɝ - ɑɹ - fɹɛnz ə tɑm, bʌɾ ɪts hɑɹd taɪmz ən stoʊni deɪz. aɪ doʊn səpoʊz jə kən peɪ? noʊ, aɪ dɪdn θɪŋk soʊ. ðɛɹz nɑɾ ɪnʌf ʌv ɛniθɪŋ, ən wʌt ðəɹ ɪz kɑsts ði ɝθ, soʊ əl ɡɪv jə bɛdz - nɑt ðə bɛst, bʌt wɔɹm ən dʒɹaɪ - ən sʌmθɪŋ tə it, ən aɪ kænɑt pɹɑməs mɔɹ, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ aɪd laɪk."

"You two look the right sort, and I do believe you were - are - friends of Thom, but it's hard times and stony days. I don't suppose you can pay? No, I didn't think so. There's not enough of anything, and what there is costs the earth, so I'll give you beds - not the best, but warm and dry - and something to eat, and I cannot promise more, however much I'd like."

"θæŋk ju," ɹænd sɛd wɪð ə kwɪtsɪkəl ɡlæns ət mæt. "ɪts mɔɹ ðən aɪ ɪkspɛktəd." wʌt wɑz ðə ɹaɪt sɔɹt, ən waɪ ʃəɾ i pɹɑməs mɔɹ?

"Thank you," Rand said with a quizzical glance at Mat. "It's more than I expected." What was the right sort, and why should he promise more?

"wɛl, tɑmz ə ɡʊd fɹɛnd. ən oʊl fɹɛnd. hɑthɛɾəd ən laɪəbəl tə seɪ ðə wɝs pɑsəbəl θɪŋ tə ðə wʌn pɝsən i ʃʊdnt, bʌɾ ə ɡʊd fɹɛn ɔl ðə seɪm. ɪf i dʌznt ʃoʊ ʌp . . . wɛl, wɪl fɪɡjɝ sʌmθɪŋ aʊt ðɛn. bɛs jə doʊn tɔk ɛni mɔɹ tɔk əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ hɛlpɪŋ ju. ɪm ə ɡʊd kwinz mæn, bʌt ðəɹ ɑɹ tu mɛni ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ɹaɪt naʊ hud teɪk ɪt ɹɔŋ, ən aɪ doʊn min dʒʌs ðə waɪtkloʊks."

"Well, Thom's a good friend. An old friend. Hotheaded and liable to say the worst possible thing to the one person he shouldn't, but a good friend all the same. If he doesn't show up . . . well, we'll figure something out then. Best you don't talk any more talk about Aes Sedai helping you. I'm a good Queen's man, but there are too many in Caemlyn right now who'd take it wrong, and I don't mean just the Whitecloaks."

mæt snɔɹɾɪd. "fɔɹ ɔl aɪ kɛɹ, ðə ɹeɪvənz kən teɪk ɛvɹi ɛɛs sədaɪ stʃɹeɪt tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl!"

Mat snorted. "For all I care, the ravens can take every Aes Sedai straight to Shayol Ghul!"

"wɑtʃ jəɹ tʌŋ," mæstɝ ɡɪl snæpt. "aɪ sɛɾ aɪ doʊn lʌv ðɛm; aɪ dɪdn seɪ ɪm ə ful θɪŋks ðəɹ bɪhaɪn ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðæts ɹɔŋ. ðə kwin səpɔɹts ɪleɪɾə, ən ðə ɡɑɹdz stæn fəɹ ðə kwin. ðə laɪt sɛn θɪŋz doʊnt ɡoʊ soʊ bæd ðət tʃeɪnʒəz. ɛniweɪ, leɪtli səm ɡɑɹdz əv fɝɡɑɾən ðɛmsɛlvz ɪnʌf tə bi ə lɪɾəl ɹʌf wɪð foʊks ðeɪ oʊvɝhɪɹ spikɪŋ əɡɛnst ɛɛs sədaɪ. nɑɾ ɑn duɾi, θæŋk ðə laɪt, bʌɾ ɪts hæpənd, dʒʌs ðə seɪm. aɪ doʊnt niɾ ɔf-duɾi ɡɑɹdz bɹeɪkɪŋ ʌp maɪ kɑmən ɹum tə titʃ jə ə lɛsən, ən aɪ doʊnt nid waɪtkloʊks ɛɡɪŋ sʌmbɑɾi ɑn tə peɪn ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ ɑn maɪ dɔɹ, soʊ ɪf jə wɑn ɛni hɛlp aʊɾ ə mi, jə dʒʌs kip θɔts əbaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ tə jɝsɛlf, ɡʊɾ əɹ bæd." hi pɔz θɔtfəli, ðən æɾəd, "meɪbi ɪts bɛs jə doʊn mɛnʃən tɑmz neɪm, iðɝ, wɛɹ ɛniwʌn bʌt mi kən hɪɹ. səm ə ðə ɡɑɹdz əv lɔŋ mɛmɹiz, ən soʊ dʌz ðə kwin. noʊ nid teɪkɪŋ tʃænsəz."

"Watch your tongue," Master Gill snapped. "I said I don't love them; I didn't say I'm a fool thinks they're behind everything that's wrong. The Queen supports Elaida, and the Guards stand for the Queen. The Light send things don't go so bad that changes. Anyway, lately some Guards have forgotten themselves enough to be a little rough with folks they overhear speaking against Aes Sedai. Not on duty, thank the Light, but it's happened, just the same. I don't need off-duty Guards breaking up my common room to teach you a lesson, and I don't need Whitecloaks egging somebody on to paint the Dragon's Fang on my door, so if you want any help out of me, you just keep thoughts about Aes Sedai to yourself, good or bad." He paused thoughtfully, then added, "Maybe it's best you don't mention Thom's name, either, where anyone but me can hear. Some of the Guards have long memories, and so does the Queen. No need taking chances."

"tɑm hæd tʃɹʌbəl wɪð ðə kwin?" ɹænd sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli, ən ði ɪnkipɝ læft.

"Thom had trouble with the Queen?" Rand said incredulously, and the innkeeper laughed.

"soʊ hi dɪdn tɛl jə ɛvɹiθɪŋ. doʊnt noʊ waɪ hi ʃʊd. ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ jə ʃʊdnt noʊ, iðɝ. nɑt laɪk ɪts ə sikɹət, ɪɡzækli. dʒju θɪŋk ɛvɹi ɡlimən θɪŋks əz mʌtʃ ə hɪmsɛlf əz tɑm dʌz? wɛl, kʌm tə θɪŋk ʌv ɪt, aɪ ɡɛs ðeɪ du, bʌɾ ɪɾ ɔlweɪz sim tə mi tɑm hæɾ ən ɛkstʃɹə hɛlpɪŋ ə θɪŋkɪŋ ə lɑɾ ə hɪmsɛlf. hi wɑzn ɔlweɪz ə ɡlimən, jə noʊ, wɑndɝɪŋ fɹəm vɪlədʒ tə vɪlədʒ ən slipɪŋ ʌndɝ ə hɛdʒ əz ɔfən əz nɑt. ðəɹ wɑz ə taɪm tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn wɑz kɔɹtbɑɝd ɹaɪt hɪɹ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ən noʊn ɪn ɛvɹi ɹɔɪəl kɔɹt fɹəm tiɹ tə mɛɹədɑn."

"So he didn't tell you everything. Don't know why he should. On the other hand, I don't know why you shouldn't know, either. Not like it's a secret, exactly. Do you think every gleeman thinks as much of himself as Thom does? Well, come to think of it, I guess they do, but it always seemed to me Thom had an extra helping of thinking a lot of himself. He wasn't always a gleeman, you know, wandering from village to village and sleeping under a hedge as often as not. There was a time Thom Merrilin was Courtbard right here in Caemlyn, and known in every royal court from Tear to Maradon."

"tɑm?" mæt sɛd.

"Thom?" Mat said.

ɹænd nɑɾəd sloʊli. hi kəd pɪktʃɝ tɑm əɾ ə kwinz kɔɹt, wɪð ɪz steɪtli mænɝ ən ɡɹæn dʒɛstʃɝz.

Rand nodded slowly. He could picture Thom at a Queen's court, with his stately manner and grand gestures.

"ðæɾ i wɑz," mæstɝ ɡɪl sɛd. "ɪt wɑz nɑt lɔŋ æftɝ tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl dəmədʒɹd daɪd ðət ðə . . . tʃɹʌbəl əbaʊɾ ɪz nɛfju kɹɑpt ʌp. ðəɹ wɝ səm sɛd tɑm wɑz, ʃæl wi seɪ, kloʊsɝ tə ðə kwin ðən wɑz pɹɑpɝ. bʌt mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz ə jʌŋ wɪɾoʊ, ən tɑm wɑz ɪn ɪz pɹaɪm, ðɛn, ən ðə kwin kən də əz ʃi wɪʃɪz ɪz ðə weɪ aɪ lʊk əɾ ɪt. oʊnli ʃiz ɔlweɪz hæɾ ə tɛmpɝ, hæz əɹ ɡʊd mɔɹɡeɪs, ən i tʊk ɔf wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd wən i lɝnd wʌt kaɪndə tʃɹʌbəl ɪz nɛfju wɑz ɪn. ðə kwin dɪdn mʌtʃ laɪk ðæt. dɪdn laɪk ɪm mɛɾəlɪŋ ɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ mæɾɝz, iðɝ. kæn seɪ aɪ θɪŋk ɪt wɑz ɹaɪt, iðɝ, nɛfju əɹ noʊ. ɛniweɪ, wən i keɪm bæk, hi sɛd səm wɝdz, ɔl ɹaɪt. wɝdz jə doʊn seɪ tə ə kwin. wɝdz jə doʊn seɪ tə ɛni wʊmən wɪð mɔɹɡeɪsəz spɪɹət. ɪleɪɾə wɑz sɛɾ əɡɛnst ɪm kəz ə hɪz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə mɪks ɪn ðə bɪznəs wɪð ɪz nɛfju, ən bɪtwin ðə kwinz tɛmpɝ ən ɪleɪɾəz ænəmɑsəɾi, tɑm lɛf keɪɛmlɪn hæf ə stɛp əhɛɾ ʌv ə tʃɹɪp tə pɹɪzən, ɪf nɑt ðə hɛdzmənz æks. əz fɑɹ əz aɪ noʊ, ðə ɹɪt stɪl stænz."

"That he was," Master Gill said. "It was not long after Taringail Damodred died that the . . . trouble about his nephew cropped up. There were some said Thom was, shall we say, closer to the Queen than was proper. But Morgase was a young widow, and Thom was in his prime, then, and the Queen can do as she wishes is the way I look at it. Only she's always had a temper, has our good Morgase, and he took off without a word when he learned what kind of trouble his nephew was in. The Queen didn't much like that. Didn't like him meddling in Aes Sedai matters, either. Can't say I think it was right, either, nephew or no. Anyway, when he came back, he said some words, all right. Words you don't say to a Queen. Words you don't say to any woman with Morgase's spirit. Elaida was set against him because of his trying to mix in the business with his nephew, and between the Queen's temper and Elaida's animosity, Thom left Caemlyn half a step ahead of a trip to prison, if not the headsman's axe. As far as I know, the writ still stands."

"ɪf ɪt wɑz ə lɔŋ taɪm əɡoʊ," ɹænd sɛd, "meɪbi noʊbɑdi ɹɪmɛmbɝz."

"If it was a long time ago," Rand said, "maybe nobody remembers."

mæstɝ ɡɪl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn ɪz kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz. hi pɝsənəli kəmændəd ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn mɔɹɡeɪs sɛn tə bɹɪŋ tɑm bæk ɪn tʃeɪnz, ən aɪ mɪsdaʊt hɪl ɛvɝ fɝɡɛt ɹɪtɝnɪŋ ɛmpti-hændəd tə faɪn tɑm hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn bæk tə ðə pæləs ən lɛft əɡɛn. ən ðə kwin nɛvɝ fɝɡɛts ɛniθɪŋ. jə ɛvɝ noʊ ə wʊmən u dɪd? maɪ, bʌt mɔɹɡeɪs wɑz ɪn ə teɪkɪŋ. əl swɛɹ ðə hoʊl sɪɾi wɔk sɑft ən wɪspɝd fəɹ ə mʌnθ. plɛnti ʌv ʌðɝ ɡɑɹdzmɪn oʊld ɪnʌf tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ, tu. noʊ, bɛs jə kip tɑm əz kloʊz ə sikɹəɾ əz jə kip ðəɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌv jʊɹz. kʌm, əl ɡɛt jə sʌmθɪŋ tə it. jə lʊk əz ɪf jəɹ bɛliz ɑɹ nɔɪŋ ət jəɹ bækboʊnz."

Master Gill shook his head. "Gareth Bryne is Captain-General of the Queen's Guards. He personally commanded the Guardsmen Morgase sent to bring Thom back in chains, and I misdoubt he'll ever forget returning empty-handed to find Thom had already been back to the Palace and left again. And the Queen never forgets anything. You ever know a woman who did? My, but Morgase was in a taking. I'll swear the whole city walked soft and whispered for a month. Plenty of other Guardsmen old enough to remember, too. No, best you keep Thom as close a secret as you keep that Aes Sedai of yours. Come, I'll get you something to eat. You look as if your bellies are gnawing at your backbones."


tʃæptɝ θɝɾisɪks


CHAPTER 36

wɛb ə ðə pæɾɝn


Web of the Pattern

mæstɝ ɡɪl tʊk əm tə ə kɔɹnɝ teɪbəl ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum ən hæd wʌn ə ðə sɝvɪŋ meɪdz bɹɪŋ əm fud. ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd wən i sɔ ðə pleɪts, wɪð ə fju θɪn slaɪsəz ʌv ɡɹeɪvi-kʌvɝd bif, ə spunfʊl ə mʌstɝd ɡɹinz, ən tu pəteɪɾoʊz ɑn itʃ. ɪt wɑz ə ɹufəl, ɹɪzaɪn hɛdʃeɪk, ðoʊ, nɑɾ æŋɡɹi. nɑɾ ɪnʌf ʌv ɛniθɪŋ, ði ɪnkipɝ hæd sɛd. pɪkɪŋ ʌp ɪz naɪf ən fɔɹk, ɹænd wʌndɝd wʌt wəd hæpən wən ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ lɛft. ɪt meɪɾ ɪz hæf-kʌvɝd pleɪt sim laɪk ə fist. ɪt meɪɾ ɪm ʃɪvɝ.

Master Gill took them to a corner table in the common room and had one of the serving maids bring them food. Rand shook his head when he saw the plates, with a few thin slices of gravy-covered beef, a spoonful of mustard greens, and two potatoes on each. It was a rueful, resigned headshake, though, not angry. Not enough of anything, the innkeeper had said. Picking up his knife and fork, Rand wondered what would happen when there was nothing left. It made his half-covered plate seem like a feast. It made him shiver.

mæstɝ ɡɪl hæd tʃoʊzən ə teɪbəl wɛl əweɪ fɹəm ɛniwʌn ɛls, ən i sæt wɪð ɪz bæk tə ðə kɔɹnɝ, wɛɹ i kəd wɑtʃ ðə ɹum. noʊbɑdi kəd ɡɛt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə oʊvɝhɪɹ wʌt ðeɪ sɛd wɪθaʊɾ ɪm siɪŋ. wən ðə meɪd lɛft, hi sɛd sɔfli, "naʊ, waɪ doʊn jə tɛl mi əbaʊt ðɪs tʃɹʌbəl ə jʊɹz? ɪf aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə hɛlp, aɪd bɛs noʊ wʌɾ aɪm ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪntu."

Master Gill had chosen a table well away from anyone else, and he sat with his back to the corner, where he could watch the room. Nobody could get close enough to overhear what they said without him seeing. When the maid left, he said softly, "Now, why don't you tell me about this trouble of yours? If I'm going to help, I'd best know what I'm getting into."

ɹænd lʊkt ət mæt, bʌt mæt wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ əɾ ɪz pleɪɾ əz ɪf i wɝ mæɾ ət ðə pəteɪtoʊ hi wɑz kʌɾɪŋ. ɹænd tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "aɪ doʊn ɹɪli ʌndɝstæn ɪt maɪsɛlf," hi bɪɡæn.

Rand looked at Mat, but Mat was frowning at his plate as if he were mad at the potato he was cutting. Rand took a deep breath. "I don't really understand it myself," he began.

hi kɛp ðə stɔɹi sɪmpəl, ən i kɛp tʃɹɑləks ən feɪdz aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. wən sʌmbɑɾi ɔfɝd hɛlp, ɪt wəd nɑt də tə tɛl əm ɪt wɑz ɔl əbaʊt feɪbəlz. bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt wɑz fɛɹ tə ʌndɝsteɪt ðə deɪnʒɝ, iðɝ, nɑt fɛɹ tə pʊl sʌmwʌn ɪn wən ðeɪ hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌt ðeɪ wɝ ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪntu. səm mɛn wɝ æftɝ ɪm ən mæt, ən ə kʌpəl ə fɹɛnz ə ðɛɹz, tu. ðeɪ əpɪɹd wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ list ɪkspɛktəd, ðiz mɛn, ən ðeɪ wɝ dɛdli deɪnʒɝəs ən sɛɾ ɑn kɪlɪŋ ɪm ən ɪz fɹɛnz, əɹ wɝs. mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd səm ə ðɛm wɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. tɑm dɪd nɑt tʃɹʌs mɔɪɹeɪn kəmplitli, bʌɾ i steɪɾ ɑn wɪð ðɛm, hi sɛd, kəz ə hɪz nɛfju. ðeɪ hæd bɪn sɛpɝeɪɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ən ətæk waɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹitʃ waɪtbɹɪdʒ, ən ðɛn, ɪn waɪtbɹɪdʒ, tɑm daɪd seɪvɪŋ əm fɹəm ənʌðɝ ətæk. ən ðəɹ hæd bɪn ʌðɝ tʃɹaɪz. hi nu ðəɹ wɝ hoʊlz ɪn ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə bɛst i kəd də ɑn ʃɔɹt noʊɾəs wɪθaʊt tɛlɪŋ mɔɹ ðən wɑz seɪf.

He kept the story simple, and he kept Trollocs and Fades out of it. When somebody offered help, it would not do to tell them it was all about fables. But he did not think it was fair to understate the danger, either, not fair to pull someone in when they had no idea what they were getting into. Some men were after him and Mat, and a couple of friends of theirs, too. They appeared where they were least expected, these men, and they were deadly dangerous and set on killing him and his friends, or worse. Moiraine said some of them were Darkfriends. Thom did not trust Moiraine completely, but he stayed on with them, he said, because of his nephew. They had been separated during an attack while trying to reach Whitebridge, and then, in Whitebridge, Thom died saving them from another attack. And there had been other tries. He knew there were holes in it, but it was the best he could do on short notice without telling more than was safe.

"wi dʒʌs kɛpt ɑn tɪl wi ɹitʃt keɪɛmlɪn," hi ɪkspleɪnd. "ðæt wɑz ðə plæn, ɝɪdʒənəli. keɪɛmlɪn, ən ðən tɑɹ vəlɑn." hi ʃɪftəɾ ənkʌmftəbli ɑn ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz tʃɛɹ. æftɝ kipɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ sikɹət fəɹ soʊ lɔŋ, ɪt fɛlt ɑd tə bi tɛlɪŋ sʌmbɑɾi ivən əz mʌtʃ əz i wɑz. "ɪf wi steɪ ɑn ðət ɹut, ði ʌðɝz wɪl bi eɪbəl tə faɪn ʌs, sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ."

"We just kept on till we reached Caemlyn," he explained. "That was the plan, originally. Caemlyn, and then Tar Valon." He shifted uncomfortably on the edge of his chair. After keeping everything secret for so long, it felt odd to be telling somebody even as much as he was. "If we stay on that route, the others will be able to find us, sooner or later."

"ɪf ðəɹ əlaɪv," mæt mʌɾɝd əɾ ɪz pleɪt.

"If they're alive," Mat muttered at his plate.

ɹænd dɪd nɑɾ ivən ɡlæns ət mæt. sʌmθɪŋ kəmpɛld ɪm tə æd, "ɪt kəd bɹɪŋ jə tʃɹʌbəl, hɛlpɪŋ ʌs."

Rand did not even glance at Mat. Something compelled him to add, "It could bring you trouble, helping us."

mæstɝ ɡɪl weɪvd ɪɾ ɔf wɪð ə plʌmp hænd. "kæn seɪ əz aɪ wɑn tʃɹʌbəl, bʌɾ ɪt wʊdn bi ðə fɝst aɪv sin. noʊ blʌɾi dɑɹkfɹɛnd wɪl meɪk mi tɝn maɪ bæk ɑn tɑmz fɹɛnz. ðɪs fɹɛn ə jʊɹz fɹəm ʌp nɔɹθ, naʊ - ɪf ʃi kʌmz tə keɪɛmlɪn, əl hɪɹ. ðəɹ ɑɹ pipəl kip ðɛɹ aɪz ɑn kʌmɪŋz ən ɡoʊɪŋz laɪk ðəɾ ɝaʊn hɪɹ, ən wɝd spɹɛdz."

Master Gill waved it off with a plump hand. "Can't say as I want trouble, but it wouldn't be the first I've seen. No bloody Darkfriend will make me turn my back on Thom's friends. This friend of yours from up north, now - if she comes to Caemlyn, I'll hear. There are people keep their eyes on comings and goings like that around here, and word spreads."

ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən æskt, "wʌɾ əbaʊɾ ɪleɪɾə?"

Rand hesitated, then asked, "What about Elaida?"

ði ɪnkipɝ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, tu, ən faɪnəli ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk soʊ. meɪbi ɪf jə dɪdn əv ə kənɛkʃən tə tɑm. ʃid wɪŋkəl ɪɾ aʊt, ən ðən wɛɹ wəd jə bi? noʊ tɛlɪŋ. meɪbi ɪn ə sɛl. meɪbi wɝs. ðeɪ seɪ ʃiz ə weɪ ʌv filɪŋ θɪŋz, wʌts hæpənd, wʌts ɡoʊɪŋ tə hæpən. ðeɪ seɪ ʃi kən kʌt ɹaɪt θɹu tə wʌɾ ə mæn wɑns tə haɪd. aɪ doʊnt noʊ, bʌɾ aɪ wʊdn ɹɪsk ɪt. ɪf ɪt wɑzn fəɹ tɑm, jə kəd ɡoʊ tə ðə ɡɑɹdz. ðeɪd teɪk kɛɹ ʌv ɛni dɑɹkfɹɛnz kwɪk ɪnʌf. bʌɾ ivən ɪf jə kəd kip tɑm kwaɪət fɹəm ðə ɡɑɹdz, wɝd wəd ɹitʃ ɪleɪɾə əz sun əz jə mɛnʃən dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ən ðən jəɹ bæk wɛɹ wi stɑɹɾəd."

The innkeeper hesitated, too, and finally shook his head. "I don't think so. Maybe if you didn't have a connection to Thom. She'd winkle it out, and then where would you be? No telling. Maybe in a cell. Maybe worse. They say she has a way of feeling things, what's happened, what's going to happen. They say she can cut right through to what a man wants to hide. I don't know, but I wouldn't risk it. If it wasn't for Thom, you could go to the Guards. They'd take care of any Darkfriends quick enough. But even if you could keep Thom quiet from the Guards, word would reach Elaida as soon as you mentioned Darkfriends, and then you're back where we started."

"noʊ ɡɑɹdz," ɹænd əɡɹid. mæt nɑɾəd vɪɡɝəsli waɪl stʌfɪŋ ə fɔɹk ɪndə hɪz maʊθ ən ɡɑt ɡɹeɪvi ɑn ɪz tʃɪn.

"No Guards," Rand agreed. Mat nodded vigorously while stuffing a fork into his mouth and got gravy on his chin.

"tʃɹʌbəl ɪz, jəɹ kɑɾ ʌp ɪn ðə fɹɪnʒɪz ə pɑlətɪks, læd, ivən ɪf ɪts nʌn ə jəɹ duɪŋ, ən pɑlətɪks ɪz ə fɑɡi maɪɹ fʊl ə sneɪks."

"Trouble is, you're caught up in the fringes of politics, lad, even if it's none of your doing, and politics is a foggy mire full of snakes."

"wʌɾ əbaʊt - " ɹænd bɪɡæn, bʌt ði ɪnkipɝ ɡɹɪməst sʌɾənli, hɪz tʃɛɹ kɹikɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz bʌlk əz i sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt.

"What about - " Rand began, but the innkeeper grimaced suddenly, his chair creaking under his bulk as he sat up straight.

ðə kʊk wɑz stændɪŋ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ tə ðə kɪtʃən, waɪpɪŋ əɹ hænz wɪð əɹ eɪpɹən. wən ʃi sɔ ði ɪnkipɝ lʊkɪŋ ʃi moʊʃən fəɹ ɪm tə kʌm, ðən vænɪʃt bæk ɪndə ðə kɪtʃən.

The cook was standing in the doorway to the kitchen, wiping her hands with her apron. When she saw the innkeeper looking she motioned for him to come, then vanished back into the kitchen.

"maɪɾ əz wɛl bi mɛɹid tə hɝ." mæstɝ ɡɪl saɪd. "faɪnz θɪŋz ðət nid fɪksɪŋ bɪfɔɹ aɪ noʊ ðɛɹz ɛniθɪŋ ɹɔŋ. ɪf ɪts nɑt ðə dʒɹeɪnz stɑpt ʌp, əɹ ðə daʊnspaʊts klɔɡd, ɪts ɹæts. aɪ kip ə klin pleɪs, jə ʌndɝstænd, bʌt wɪð soʊ mɛni pipəl ɪn ðə sɪɾi, ɹæts ɑɹ ɛvɹiwɛɹ. kɹaʊd pipəl təɡɛðɝ ən jə ɡɛt ɹæts, ən keɪɛmlɪn əz ə pleɪɡ ʌv əm ɔl ʌv ə sʌɾən. jə wʊdn bɪliv wʌɾ ə ɡʊd kæt, ə pɹaɪm ɹæɾɝ, fɛtʃɪz ðiz deɪz. jəɹ ɹum ɪz ɪn ði æɾɪk. əl tɛl ðə ɡɝlz wɪtʃ; ɛni ʌv əm kən ʃoʊ jə tə ɪt. ən doʊnt wɝi əbaʊt dɑɹkfɹɛnz. aɪ kæn seɪ mʌtʃ ɡʊɾ əbaʊt ðə waɪtkloʊks, bʌt bɪtwin əm ən ðə ɡɑɹdz, ðət sɔɹt woʊn dɛɹ ʃoʊ ðɛɹ fɪlθi feɪsəz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn." hɪz tʃɛɹ skwikt əɡɛn əz i pʊʃt ɪt bæk ən stʊd. "aɪ hoʊp ɪɾ ɪzən ðə dʒɹeɪnz əɡɛn."

"Might as well be married to her." Master Gill sighed. "Finds things that need fixing before I know there's anything wrong. If it's not the drains stopped up, or the downspouts clogged, it's rats. I keep a clean place, you understand, but with so many people in the city, rats are everywhere. Crowd people together and you get rats, and Caemlyn has a plague of them all of a sudden. You wouldn't believe what a good cat, a prime ratter, fetches these days. Your room is in the attic. I'll tell the girls which; any of them can show you to it. And don't worry about Darkfriends. I can't say much good about the Whitecloaks, but between them and the Guards, that sort won't dare show their filthy faces in Caemlyn." His chair squeaked again as he pushed it back and stood. "I hope it isn't the drains again."

ɹænd wɛn bæk tə hɪz fud, bʌɾ i sɔ ðət mæt hæd stɑpt iɾɪŋ. "aɪ θɔt jə wɝ hʌŋɡɹi," hi sɛd. mæt kɛp stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪz pleɪt, pʊʃɪŋ wʌn pis ə pəteɪtoʊ ɪn ə sɝkəl wɪð ɪz fɔɹk. "ju hæv tə it, mæt. wi nid tə kip ʌp əɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪf wɝ gɑnə ɹitʃ tɑɹ vəlɑn."

Rand went back to his food, but he saw that Mat had stopped eating. "I thought you were hungry," he said. Mat kept staring at his plate, pushing one piece of potato in a circle with his fork. "You have to eat, Mat. We need to keep up our strength if we're going to reach Tar Valon."

mæt lɛɾ aʊɾ ə loʊ, bɪɾɝ læf. "tɑɹ vəlɑn! ɔl ðɪs taɪm ɪts bɪn keɪɛmlɪn. mɔɪɹeɪn wəd bi weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ əs ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. wid faɪn pɛɹɪn ən ɛɡwin ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wəd bi ɔl ɹaɪɾ ɪf wi oʊnli ɡɑt tə keɪɛmlɪn. wɛl, hɪɹ wi ɑɹ, ən nʌθɪŋz ɹaɪt. noʊ mɔɪɹeɪn, noʊ pɛɹɪn, noʊ ɛnibəɾi. naʊ ɪts ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɪl bi ɔl ɹaɪɾ ɪf wi oʊnli ɡɛt tə tɑɹ vəlɑn."

Mat let out a low, bitter laugh. "Tar Valon! All this time it's been Caemlyn. Moiraine would be waiting for us in Caemlyn. We'd find Perrin and Egwene in Caemlyn. Everything would be all right if we only got to Caemlyn. Well, here we are, and nothing's right. No Moiraine, no Perrin, no anybody. Now it's everything will be all right if we only get to Tar Valon."

"wɝ əlaɪv," ɹænd sɛd, mɔɹ ʃɑɹpli ðən i hæɾ ɪntɛndəd. hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ ən tʃɹaɪd tə mɑɾɝeɪt ɪz toʊn. "wi ɑɹ əlaɪv. ðət mʌtʃ ɪz ɔl ɹaɪt. ən aɪ ɪntɛn tə steɪ əlaɪv. aɪ ɪntɛn tə faɪn aʊt waɪ wɝ soʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt. aɪ woʊnt ɡɪv ʌp."

"We're alive," Rand said, more sharply than he had intended. He took a deep breath and tried to moderate his tone. "We are alive. That much is all right. And I intend to stay alive. I intend to find out why we're so important. I won't give up."

"ɔl ðiz pipəl, ən ɛni ʌv əm kəd bi dɑɹkfɹɛnz. mæstɝ ɡɪl pɹɑməs tə hɛlp əs ɑfli kwɪk. wʌt kaɪndə mæn dʒʌst ʃɹʌɡz ɔf ɛɛs sədaɪ ən dɑɹkfɹɛnz? ɪɾ ɪzənt nætʃɹəl. ɛni disən pɝsən wəd tɛl əs tə ɡɛɾ aʊt, əɹ . . . əɹ . . . əɹ sʌmθɪŋ."

"All these people, and any of them could be Darkfriends. Master Gill promised to help us awfully quick. What kind of man just shrugs off Aes Sedai and Darkfriends? It isn't natural. Any decent person would tell us to get out, or . . . or . . . or something."

"it," ɹænd sɛd dʒɛnli, ən wɑtʃt əntɪl mæt bɪɡæn tʃuɪŋ ə pis ə bif.

"Eat," Rand said gently, and watched until Mat began chewing a piece of beef.

hi lɛft ɪz oʊn hænz ɹɛstɪŋ bɪsaɪɾ ɪz pleɪt fəɹ ə mɪnət, pɹɛsɪŋ əm əɡɛns ðə teɪbəl tə kip əm fɹəm ʃeɪkɪŋ. hi wɑz skɛɹd. nɑɾ əbaʊt mæstɝ ɡɪl, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ɪnʌf wɪθaʊt ðæt. ðoʊz tɔl sɪɾi wɔlz wəd nɑt stɑp ə feɪd. meɪbi hi ʃəd tɛl ði ɪnkipɝ əbaʊt ðæt. bʌɾ ivən ɪf ɡɪl bɪlivd, wəɾ i bi əz wɪlɪŋ tə hɛlp ɪf i θɔɾ ə feɪd maɪt ʃoʊ ʌp ət ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ? ən ðə ɹæts. meɪbi ɹæts dɪd θɹaɪv wɛɹ ðəɹ wɝ ə lɑɾ ə pipəl, bʌɾ i ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðə dʒɹim ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə dʒɹim ɪn bɛɹlən, ən ə smɔl spaɪn snæpɪŋ. səmtaɪmz ðə dɑɹk wʌn juzɪz kɛɹiən iɾɝz əz ɪz aɪz, læn hæd sɛd. ɹeɪvənz, kɹoʊz, ɹæts. . . .

He left his own hands resting beside his plate for a minute, pressing them against the table to keep them from shaking. He was scared. Not about Master Gill, of course, but there was enough without that. Those tall city walls would not stop a Fade. Maybe he should tell the innkeeper about that. But even if Gill believed, would he be as willing to help if he thought a Fade might show up at The Queen's Blessing? And the rats. Maybe rats did thrive where there were a lot of people, but he remembered the dream that was not a dream in Baerlon, and a small spine snapping. Sometimes the Dark One uses carrion eaters as his eyes, Lan had said. Ravens, crows, rats. . . .

hi eɪt, bʌt wən i wɑz dʌn i kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ teɪstɪŋ ə sɪŋɡəl baɪt.

He ate, but when he was done he could not remember tasting a single bite.

ə sɝvɪŋ meɪd, ðə wʌn u hæd bɪn pɑlɪʃɪŋ kændəlstɪks wən ðeɪ keɪm ɪn, ʃoʊɾ əm ʌp tə ði æɾɪk ɹum. ə dɔɹmɝ wɪndoʊ pɪɹs ðə slæntɪŋ aʊɾɝ wɔl, wɪð ə bɛɾ ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ʌv ɪɾ ən pɛɡz bɪsaɪd ðə dɔɹ fəɹ hæŋɪŋ ðɛɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz. ðə dɑɹk-aɪd ɡɝl hæɾ ə tɛndənsi tə twɪst əɹ skɝɾ ən ɡɪɡəl wɛnɛvɝ ʃi lʊkt ət ɹænd. ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi, bʌɾ i nu ɪf i sɛɾ ɛniθɪŋ tə hɝ i wəd dʒʌs meɪk ə ful ə hɪmsɛlf. ʃi meɪɾ ɪm wɪʃ i hæd pɛɹɪnz weɪ wɪð ɡɝlz; hi wɑz ɡlæd wən ʃi lɛft.

A serving maid, the one who had been polishing candlesticks when they came in, showed them up to the attic room. A dormer window pierced the slanting outer wall, with a bed on either side of it and pegs beside the door for hanging their belongings. The dark-eyed girl had a tendency to twist her skirt and giggle whenever she looked at Rand. She was pretty, but he knew if he said anything to her he would just make a fool of himself. She made him wish he had Perrin's way with girls; he was glad when she left.

hi ɪkspɛktəd səm kɑmɛn fɹəm mæt, bʌɾ əz sun əz ʃi wɑz ɡɔn, mæt θɹu hɪmsɛlf ɑn wʌn ə ðə bɛdz, stɪl ɪn ɪz kloʊk ən buts, ən tɝn ɪz feɪs tə ðə wɔl.

He expected some comment from Mat, but as soon as she was gone, Mat threw himself on one of the beds, still in his cloak and boots, and turned his face to the wall.

ɹænd hʌŋ ɪz θɪŋz ʌp, wɑtʃɪŋ mæts bæk. hi θɔt mæt hæɾ ɪz hæn ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt, klʌtʃɪŋ ðət dæɡɝ əɡɛn.
