Rand hung his things up, watching Mat's back. He thought Mat had his hand under his coat, clutching that dagger again.

"ju dʒʌs gɑnə laɪ ʌp hɪɹ haɪɾɪŋ?" hi sɛd faɪnəli.

"You just going to lie up here hiding?" he said finally.

"aɪm taɪɝd," mæt mʌmbəld.

"I'm tired," Mat mumbled.

"wi hæv kwɛstʃənz tə æsk mæstɝ ɡɪl, jɛt. hi maɪɾ ivən bi eɪbəl tə tɛl əs haʊ tə faɪn ɛɡwin, ən pɛɹɪn. ðeɪ kəd bi ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ɔlɹɛɾi ɪf ðeɪ mænədʒ tə hæŋ ɑntu ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz."

"We have questions to ask Master Gill, yet. He might even be able to tell us how to find Egwene, and Perrin. They could be in Caemlyn already if they managed to hang onto their horses."

"ðeɪɹ dɛd," mæt sɛd tə ðə wɔl.

"They're dead," Mat said to the wall.

ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən ɡeɪv ʌp. hi kloʊz ðə dɔɹ sɔfli bɪhaɪn hɪm, hoʊpɪŋ mæt ɹɪli wəd slip.

Rand hesitated, then gave up. He closed the door softly behind him, hoping Mat really would sleep.

daʊnstɛɹz, haʊɛvɝ, mæstɝ ɡɪl wɑz noʊwɛɹ tə bi faʊnd, ðoʊ ðə ʃɑɹp lʊk ɪn ðə kʊks aɪ sɛd ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ fəɹ hɪm, tu. fəɹ ə waɪl ɹænd sæɾ ɪn ðə kɑmən ɹum, bʌɾ i faʊn hɪmsɛlf aɪɪŋ ɛvɹi peɪtʃɹən u keɪm ɪn, ɛvɹi stʃɹeɪnʒɝ u kəd bi ɛniwʌn - əɹ ɛniθɪŋ - ɪspɛʃli ɪn ðə moʊmənt wən i wɑz fɝst sɪləuɛɾɪd əz ə kloʊk blæk ʃeɪp ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ. eɪ feɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹum wəd bi laɪk ə fɑks ɪn ə tʃɪkən kup.

Downstairs, however, Master Gill was nowhere to be found, though the sharp look in the cook's eye said she was looking for him, too. For a while Rand sat in the common room, but he found himself eyeing every patron who came in, every stranger who could be anyone - or anything - especially in the moment when he was first silhouetted as a cloaked black shape in the doorway. A Fade in the room would be like a fox in a chicken coop.

eɪ ɡɑɹdzmæn ɛntɝd fɹəm ðə stʃɹit. ðə ɹɛd-junəfɔɹmd mæn stɑp dʒʌst ɪnsaɪd ðə dɔɹ, ɹʌnɪŋ ə kul aɪ oʊvɝ ðoʊz ɪn ðə ɹum u wɝ ɑbviəsli fɹəm aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi. ɹænd stʌɾid ðə teɪbəltɑp wən ðə ɡɑɹdzmænz aɪz fɛl ɑn hɪm; wən i lʊkt ʌp əɡɛn, ðə mæn wɑz ɡɔn.

A Guardsman entered from the street. The red-uniformed man stopped just inside the door, running a cool eye over those in the room who were obviously from outside the city. Rand studied the tabletop when the Guardsman's eyes fell on him; when he looked up again, the man was gone.

ðə dɑɹk-aɪd meɪd wɑz pæsɪŋ wɪð əɹ ɑɹmz fʊl ə taʊəlz. "ðeɪ də ðət səmtaɪmz," ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə kənfaɪɾɪŋ toʊn əz ʃi wɛn baɪ. "dʒʌs tə si ðɛɹz noʊ tʃɹʌbəl. ðeɪ lʊk æftɝ ɡʊd kwinz foʊk, ðeɪ du. nʌθɪŋ fəɹ jə tə wɝi əbaʊt." ʃi ɡɪɡəld.

The dark-eyed maid was passing with her arms full of towels. "They do that sometimes," she said in a confiding tone as she went by. "Just to see there's no trouble. They look after good Queen's folk, they do. Nothing for you to worry about." She giggled.

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ɪm tə wɝi əbaʊt. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əz ɪf ðə ɡɑɹdzmæn wʊɾə kʌm oʊvɝ ən dɪmændəd tə noʊ ɪf i nu tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn. hi wɑz ɡɛɾɪŋ əz bæɾ əz mæt. hi skɹeɪp bæk ɪz tʃɛɹ.

Rand shook his head. Nothing for him to worry about. It was not as if the Guardsman would have come over and demanded to know if he knew Thom Merrilin. He was getting as bad as Mat. He scraped back his chair.

ənʌðɝ meɪd wɑz tʃɛkɪŋ ði ɔɪl ɪn ðə læmps əlɔŋ ðə wɔl.

Another maid was checking the oil in the lamps along the wall.

"ɪz ðəɹ ənʌðɝ ɹum wɛɹ aɪ kəd sɪt?" hi æsk hɝ. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɡoʊ bæk əpstɛɹz ən ʃʌt hɪmsɛlf ʌp wɪð mæts sʌlən wɪðdʒɹɔəl. "meɪbi ə pɹaɪvət daɪnɪŋ ɹum ðæts nɑt biɪŋ juzd?"

"Is there another room where I could sit?" he asked her. He did not want to go back upstairs and shut himself up with Mat's sullen withdrawal. "Maybe a private dining room that's not being used?"

"ðɛɹz ðə laɪbɹɛɹi." ʃi pɔɪntəd tə ə dɔɹ. "θɹu ðɛɹ, tə jəɹ ɹaɪt, ət ði ɛn ə ðə hɔl. maɪt bi ɛmpti, ðɪs aʊɝ."

"There's the library." She pointed to a door. "Through there, to your right, at the end of the hall. Might be empty, this hour."

"θæŋk ju. ɪf jə si mæstɝ ɡɪl, wəd jə tɛl ɪm ɹænd ælθɹ nidz tə tɔk tə hɪm ɪf i kən spɛɹ ə mɪnət?"

"Thank you. If you see Master Gill, would you tell him Rand al'Thor needs to talk to him if he can spare a minute?"

"aɪl tɛl hɪm," ʃi sɛd, ðən ɡɹɪnd. "kʊk wɑns tə tɔk tə hɪm, tu."

"I'll tell him," she said, then grinned. "Cook wants to talk to him, too."

ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz pɹɑbli haɪɾɪŋ, hi θɔɾ əz i tɝn əweɪ fɹəm hɝ.

The innkeeper was probably hiding, he thought as he turned away from her.

wən i stɛpt ɪndə ðə ɹum tə wɪtʃ ʃi hæd dɝɛktəd hɪm, hi stɑpt ən stɛɹd. ðə ʃɛlvz mʌst əv hɛl θɹi əɹ fɔɹ hʌnʒɹəd bʊks, mɔɹ ðən i hæɾ ɛvɝ sin ɪn wʌn pleɪs bɪfɔɹ. klɑθbaʊnd, lɛðɝbaʊnd wɪð ɡɪldɪd spaɪnz. oʊnli ə fju hæd wʊɾən kʌvɝz. hɪz aɪz ɡɑbəld ʌp ðə taɪɾəlz, pɪkɪŋ aʊɾ oʊl feɪvɹɪts. ðə tʃɹævəlz ə dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ. ði ɛseɪz ʌv wɪlɪm ə meɪnɪtʃɪz. hɪz bɹɛθ kɑɾ ət ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə lɛðɝbaʊn kɑpi ʌv vɔɪədʒəz əmʌŋ ðə si foʊk. tæm hæɾ ɔlweɪz wɑntəd tə ɹid ðæt.

When he stepped into the room to which she had directed him, he stopped and stared. The shelves must have held three or four hundred books, more than he had ever seen in one place before. Clothbound, leatherbound with gilded spines. Only a few had wooden covers. His eyes gobbled up the titles, picking out old favorites. The Travels of Jain Farstrider. The Essays of Willim of Maneches. His breath caught at the sight of a leatherbound copy of Voyages Among the Sea Folk. Tam had always wanted to read that.

pɪktʃɝɪŋ tæm, tɝnɪŋ ðə bʊk oʊvɝ ɪn ɪz hænz wɪð ə smaɪl, ɡɛɾɪŋ ðə fil ʌv ɪt bɪfɔɹ sɛɾəlɪŋ daʊn bɪfɔɹ ðə faɪɝpleɪs wɪð ɪz paɪp tə ɹid, hɪz oʊn hæn taɪɾənd ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt wɪð ə sɛns ə lɔs ən ɛmptinəs ðət dæmpən ɔl ɪz plɛʒɝ ɪn ðə bʊks.

Picturing Tam, turning the book over in his hands with a smile, getting the feel of it before settling down before the fireplace with his pipe to read, his own hand tightened on his sword hilt with a sense of loss and emptiness that dampened all his pleasure in the books.

ə θɹoʊt klɪɹd bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən i sʌɾənli ɹilaɪzd i wɑz nɑɾ əloʊn. ɹɛɾi tə əpɑlədʒaɪz fəɹ ɪz ɹudnəs, hi tɝnd. hi wɑz juz tə biɪŋ tɔlɝ ðən ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn i mɛt, bʌt ðɪs taɪm ɪz aɪz tʃɹævəld ʌp ən ʌp ən ʌp, ən ɪz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən. ðən i keɪm tə ðə hɛɾ ɔlmoʊst ɹitʃɪŋ ðə tɛn-fʊt silɪŋ. ə noʊz əz bɹɔɾ əz ðə feɪs, soʊ waɪɾ ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ə snaʊt ðən ə noʊz. aɪbɹaʊz ðət hʌŋ daʊn laɪk teɪlz, fɹeɪmɪŋ peɪl aɪz əz bɪɡ əz tikəps. ɪɹz ðət poʊkt ʌp tə tʌftəd pɔɪns θɹu ə ʃæɡi, blæk meɪn. tʃɹɑlɑk! hi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə jɛl ən tʃɹaɪd tə bæk ʌp ən dʒɹɔ hɪz sɔɹd. hɪz fit ɡɑt tæŋɡəld, ən i sæt daʊn hɑɹd, ɪnstɛd.

A throat cleared behind him, and he suddenly realized he was not alone. Ready to apologize for his rudeness, he turned. He was used to being taller than almost everyone he met, but this time his eyes traveled up and up and up, and his mouth fell open. Then he came to the head almost reaching the ten-foot ceiling. A nose as broad as the face, so wide it was more a snout than a nose. Eyebrows that hung down like tails, framing pale eyes as big as teacups. Ears that poked up to tufted points through a shaggy, black mane. Trolloc! He let out a yell and tried to back up and draw his sword. His feet got tangled, and he sat down hard, instead.

"aɪ wɪʃ jə hjumənz wʊdn də ðæt," ɹʌmbəld ə vɔɪs əz dip əz ə dʒɹʌm. ðə tʌftəɾ ɪɹz twɪtʃt vaɪələnli, ən ðə vɔɪs bɪkeɪm sæd. "soʊ fju ʌv jə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ʌs. ɪts əɹ oʊn fɔlt, aɪ səpoʊz. nɑt mɛni ʌv əs əv ɡɔn aʊɾ əmʌŋ mɛn sɪns ðə ʃædoʊ fɛl ɑn ðə weɪz. ðæts . . . oʊ, sɪks dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz, naʊ. ɹaɪɾ æftɝ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ɪt wɑz." ðə ʃæɡi hɛd ʃʊk ən lɛɾ aʊɾ ə saɪ ðət wʊɾə dʌn kɹɛɾət tə ə bʊl. "tu lɔŋ, tu lɔŋ, ən soʊ fju tə tʃɹævəl ən si, ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn nʌn."

"I wish you humans wouldn't do that," rumbled a voice as deep as a drum. The tufted ears twitched violently, and the voice became sad. "So few of you remember us. It's our own fault, I suppose. Not many of us have gone out among men since the Shadow fell on the Ways. That's . . . oh, six generations, now. Right after the War of the Hundred Years, it was." The shaggy head shook and let out a sigh that would have done credit to a bull. "Too long, too long, and so few to travel and see, it might as well have been none."

ɹænd sæt ðəɹ fəɹ ə mɪnət wɪð ɪz maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən, stɛɹɪŋ ʌp ət ði æpɝɪʃən ɪn waɪd-toʊd, ni-haɪ buts ən ə dɑɹk blu koʊt ðət bʌɾənd fɹəm ðə nɛk tə ðə weɪst, ðən flɛɹɾ aʊt tə hɪz but tɑps laɪk ə kɪlt oʊvɝ bæɡi tʃɹaʊzɝz. ɪn wʌn hænd wɑz ə bʊk, simɪŋ taɪni baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən, wɪð ə fɪŋɡɝ bɹɔɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ θɹi mɑɹkɪŋ ðə pleɪs.

Rand sat there for a minute with his mouth hanging open, staring up at the apparition in wide-toed, knee-high boots and a dark blue coat that buttoned from the neck to the waist, then flared out to his boot tops like a kilt over baggy trousers. In one hand was a book, seeming tiny by comparison, with a finger broad enough for three marking the place.

"aɪ θɔt jə wɝ - " hi bɪɡæn, ðən kɑt hɪmsɛlf. "wʌɾ ɑɹ - ?" ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɛni bɛɾɝ. ɡɛɾɪŋ tə hɪz fit, hi dʒɪnʒɝli ɔfɝɾ ɪz hænd. "maɪ neɪm ɪz ɹænd ælθɹ."

"I thought you were - " he began, then caught himself. "What are - ?" That was not any better. Getting to his feet, he gingerly offered his hand. "My name is Rand al'Thor."

ə hæn əz bɪɡ əz ə hæm ɪnɡʌlf hɪz; ɪt wɑz əkʌmpənid baɪ ə fɔɹməl baʊ. "lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹən sʌn ə hɑlən. jəɹ neɪm sɪŋz ɪn maɪ ɪɹz, ɹænd ælθɹ."

A hand as big as a ham engulfed his; it was accompanied by a formal bow. "Loial, son of Arent son of Halan. Your name sings in my ears, Rand al'Thor."

ðət saʊndəd laɪk ə ɹɪtʃuəl ɡɹiɾɪŋ tə ɹænd. hi ɹɪtɝn ðə baʊ. "jɔɹ neɪm sɪŋz ɪn maɪ ɪɹz, lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹənt . . . ɑ . . . sʌn ə hɑlən."

That sounded like a ritual greeting to Rand. He returned the bow. "Your name sings in my ears, Loial, son of Arent . . . ah . . . son of Halan."

ɪt wɑz ɔl ə lɪɾəl ənɹil. hi stɪl dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt lɔɪəl wɑz. ðə ɡɹɪp ə lɔɪəlz hjudʒ fɪŋɡɝz wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli dʒɛntəl, bʌɾ i wɑz stɪl ɹɪliv tə ɡɛɾ ɪz hæn bæk ɪn wʌn pis.

It was all a little unreal. He still did not know what Loial was. The grip of Loial's huge fingers was surprisingly gentle, but he was still relieved to get his hand back in one piece.

"ju hjumənz ɑɹ vɛɹi ɪksaɪɾəbəl," lɔɪəl sɛɾ ɪn ðət bæs ɹʌmbəl. "aɪ hæd hɝɾ ɔl ðə stɔɹiz, ən ɹɛd ðə bʊks, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ aɪ dɪdn ɹilaɪz. maɪ fɝs deɪ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, aɪ kəd nɑt bɪliv ði ʌpɹɔɹ. tʃɪlʒɹən kɹaɪd, ən wɪmən skɹimd, ən ə mɑb tʃeɪs mi ɔl ðə weɪ əkɹɔs ðə sɪɾi, weɪvɪŋ klʌbz ən naɪvz ən tɔɹtʃɪz, ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ, 'tʃɹɑlɑk!' aɪm əfɹeɪɾ aɪ wɑz ɔlmoʊs bɪɡɪnɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ ə lɪɾəl ʌpsɛt. ðɛɹz noʊ tɛlɪŋ wʌt wʊɾə hæpən ɪf ə pɑɹɾi ʌv ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz hædn kʌm əlɔŋ."

"You humans are very excitable," Loial said in that bass rumble. "I had heard all the stories, and read the books, of course, but I didn't realize. My first day in Caemlyn, I could not believe the uproar. Children cried, and women screamed, and a mob chased me all the way across the city, waving clubs and knives and torches, and shouting, 'Trolloc!' I'm afraid I was almost beginning to get a little upset. There's no telling what would have happened if a party of the Queen's Guards hadn't come along."

"ə lʌki θɪŋ," ɹænd sɛd feɪnli.

"A lucky thing," Rand said faintly.

"jɛs, bʌɾ ivən ðə ɡɑɹdzmɪn simd ɔlmoʊst əz əfɹeɪɾ ə mi əz ði ʌðɝz. fɔɹ deɪz ɪn keɪɛmlɪn naʊ, ən aɪ hævən bɪn eɪbəl tə pʊt maɪ noʊz aʊtsaɪd ðɪs ɪn. ɡʊd mæstɝ ɡɪl ivən æsk mi nɑt tə juz ðə kɑmən ɹum." hɪz ɪɹz twɪtʃt. "nɑt ðəɾ i hæzən bɪn vɛɹi hɑspɪɾəbəl, jə ʌndɝstænd. bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə bɪɾ ə tʃɹʌbəl ðət fɝs naɪt. ɔl ðə hjumənz sim tə wɑnə liv ət wʌns. sətʃ skɹimɪŋ ən ʃaʊɾɪŋ, ɛvɹiwʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɡɛt θɹu ðə dɔɹ ət ðə seɪm taɪm. səm ə ðɛm cʊɾə bɪn hɝt."

"Yes, but even the Guardsmen seemed almost as afraid of me as the others. Four days in Caemlyn now, and I haven't been able to put my nose outside this inn. Good Master Gill even asked me not to use the common room." His ears twitched. "Not that he hasn't been very hospitable, you understand. But there was a bit of trouble that first night. All the humans seemed to want to leave at once. Such screaming and shouting, everyone trying to get through the door at the same time. Some of them could have been hurt."

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ɪn fæsəneɪʃən ət ðoʊz twɪtʃɪŋ ɪɹz.

Rand stared in fascination at those twitching ears.

"aɪl tɛl ju, ɪt wɑz nɑt fəɹ ðɪs aɪ lɛf ðə stɛɾɪŋ."

"I'll tell you, it was not for this I left the stedding."

"jɔɹ ən oʊɡiɝ!" ɹænd ɪkskleɪmd. "weɪt! sɪks dʒɛnɝeɪʃənz? jə sɛd ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz! haʊ oʊld ɑɹ ju?" hi nu ɪt wɑz ɹuɾ əz sun əz i sɛɾ ɪt, bʌt lɔɪəl bɪkeɪm dɪfɛnsɪv ɹæðɝ ðən əfɛndəd.

"You're an Ogier!" Rand exclaimed. "Wait! Six generations? You said the War of the Hundred Years! How old are you?" He knew it was rude as soon as he said it, but Loial became defensive rather than offended.

"naɪnti jɪɹz," ði oʊɡiɝ sɛd stɪfli. "ɪn oʊnli tɛn mɔɹ əl bi eɪbəl tə ædʒɹɛs ðə stʌmp. aɪ θɪŋk ði ɛldɝz ʃʊɾə lemi spik, sɪns ðeɪ wɝ dəsaɪɾɪŋ wɛðɝ aɪ kəd liv əɹ nɑt. bʌt ðən ðeɪ ɔlweɪz wɝi əbaʊɾ ɛniwʌn ʌv ɛni eɪdʒ ɡoʊɪŋ aʊtsaɪd. jə hjumənz ɑɹ soʊ heɪsti, soʊ ɪɹæɾɪk." hi blɪŋkt ən ɡeɪv ə ʃɔɹt baʊ. "pliz fɝɡɪv mi. aɪ ʃʊdn əv sɛd ðæt. bʌt jə də faɪɾ ɔl ðə taɪm, ivən wən ðɛɹz noʊ nid tə."

"Ninety years," the Ogier said stiffly. "In only ten more I'll be able to address the Stump. I think the Elders should have let me speak, since they were deciding whether I could leave or not. But then they always worry about anyone of any age going Outside. You humans are so hasty, so erratic." He blinked and gave a short bow. "Please forgive me. I shouldn't have said that. But you do fight all the time, even when there's no need to."

"ðæts ɔl ɹaɪt," ɹænd sɛd. hi wɑz stɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə teɪk ɪn lɔɪəlz eɪdʒ. oʊldɝ ðən oʊl sɛn bui, ən stɪl nɑɾ oʊld ɪnʌf tə. . . . hi sæt daʊn ɪn wʌn ə ðə haɪ-bæk tʃɛɹz. lɔɪəl tʊk ənʌðɝ, meɪd tə hoʊl tu; hi fɪld ɪt. sɪɾɪŋ, hi wɑz əz tɔl əz moʊs mɛn stændɪŋ. "æt lis ðeɪ dɪd lɛt jə ɡoʊ."

"That's all right," Rand said. He was still trying to take in Loial's age. Older than old Cenn Buie, and still not old enough to. . . . He sat down in one of the high-backed chairs. Loial took another, made to hold two; he filled it. Sitting, he was as tall as most men standing. "At least they did let you go."

lɔɪəl lʊkt ət ðə flɔɹ, ɹɪŋkəlɪŋ ɪz noʊz ən ɹʌbɪŋ əɾ ɪt wɪð wʌn θɪk fɪŋɡɝ. "wɛl, əz tə ðæt, naʊ. jə si, ðə stʌmp hæd nɑt bɪn miɾɪŋ vɛɹi lɔŋ, nɑɾ ivən ə jɪɹ, bʌɾ aɪ kəd tɛl fɹəm wʌɾ aɪ hɝd ðət baɪ ðə taɪm ðeɪ ɹitʃt ə dɪsɪʒən aɪ wəd bi oʊld ɪnʌf tə ɡoʊ wɪθaʊt ðɛɹ pɝmɪʃən. aɪm əfɹeɪd ðəl seɪ aɪ pʊɾ ə lɔŋ hændəl ɑn maɪ æks, bʌɾ aɪ dʒʌst . . . lɛft. ði ɛldɝz ɔlweɪz sɛɾ aɪ wɑz tu hɑthɛɾəd, ən aɪ fɪɹ aɪv pɹuvən əm ɹaɪt. aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf ðeɪv ɹilaɪzd aɪm ɡɔn, jɛt? bʌɾ aɪ hæd tə ɡoʊ."

Loial looked at the floor, wrinkling his nose and rubbing at it with one thick finger. "Well, as to that, now. You see, the Stump had not been meeting very long, not even a year, but I could tell from what I heard that by the time they reached a decision I would be old enough to go without their permission. I am afraid they'll say I put a long handle on my axe, but I just . . . left. The Elders always said I was too hotheaded, and I fear I've proven them right. I wonder if they have realized I'm gone, yet? But I had to go."

ɹænd bɪɾ ɪz lɪp tə kip fɹəm læfɪŋ. ɪf lɔɪəl wɑz ə hɑthɛɾəd oʊɡiɝ, hi kəɾ ɪmædʒən wʌt moʊst oʊɡiɝ wɝ laɪk. hæd nɑt bɪn miɾɪŋ vɛɹi lɔŋ, nɑɾ ivən ə jɪɹ? mæstɝ ælvɪɹ wəd dʒʌst ʃeɪk ɪz hɛɾ ɪn wʌndɝ; ə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl miɾɪŋ ðət læstəd hæf ə deɪ wəɾ əv ɛvɹibɑɾi dʒʌmpɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn, ivən hɹəl luhən. ə weɪv ə hoʊmsɪknəs swɛpt oʊvɝ hɪm, meɪkɪŋ ɪt hɑɹd tə bɹið fəɹ mɛmɹiz ə tæm, ən ɛɡwin, ən ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn, ən bɛl taɪn ɑn ðə ɡɹin ɪn hæpiɝ deɪz. hi fɔɹst əm əweɪ.

Rand bit his lip to keep from laughing. If Loial was a hotheaded Ogier, he could imagine what most Ogier were like. Had not been meeting very long, not even a year? Master al'Vere would just shake his head in wonder; a Village Council meeting that lasted half a day would have everybody jumping up and down, even Haral Luhhan. A wave of homesickness swept over him, making it hard to breathe for memories of Tam, and Egwene, and the Winespring Inn, and Bel Tine on the Green in happier days. He forced them away.

"ɪf jə doʊn maɪn maɪ æskɪŋ," hi sɛd, klɪɹɪŋ ɪz θɹoʊt, "waɪ dɪd jə wɑnə ɡoʊ . . . ɑ, aʊtsaɪd, soʊ mʌtʃ? aɪ wɪʃ aɪd nɛvɝ lɛf maɪ hoʊm, maɪsɛlf."

"If you don't mind my asking," he said, clearing his throat, "why did you want to go . . . ah, Outside, so much? I wish I'd never left my home, myself."

"waɪ, tə si," lɔɪəl sɛɾ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ðə moʊst ɑbviəs θɪŋ ɪn ðə wɝld. "aɪ ɹɛd ðə bʊks, ɔl ðə tʃɹævəlɝz' əkaʊns, ən ɪt bɪɡæn tə bɝn ɪn mi ðəɾ aɪ hæd tə si, nɑt dʒʌst ɹɛd." hɪz peɪl aɪz bɹaɪɾənd, ən ɪz ɪɹz stɪfənd. "aɪ stʌɾid ɛvɹi skɹæp aɪ kəd faɪn əbaʊt tʃɹævlɪŋ, əbaʊt ðə weɪz, ən kʌstəmz ɪn hjumən lænz, ən ðə sɪɾiz wi bɪl fəɹ jə hjumənz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ən ðə mɔɹ aɪ ɹɛd, ðə mɔɹ aɪ nu ðəɾ aɪ hæd tə ɡoʊ aʊtsaɪd, ɡoʊ tə ðoʊz pleɪsəz wi hæd bɪn, ən si ðə ɡɹoʊvz fəɹ maɪsɛlf."

"Why, to see," Loial said as if it were the most obvious thing in the world. "I read the books, all the travelers' accounts, and it began to burn in me that I had to see, not just read." His pale eyes brightened, and his ears stiffened. "I studied every scrap I could find about traveling, about the Ways, and customs in human lands, and the cities we built for you humans after the Breaking of the World. And the more I read, the more I knew that I had to go Outside, go to those places we had been, and see the groves for myself."

ɹænd blɪŋkt. "ɡɹoʊvz?"

Rand blinked. "Groves?"

"jɛs, ðə ɡɹoʊvz. ðə tʃɹiz. oʊnli ə fju ʌv ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz, ʌv kɔɹs, taʊɝɪŋ tə ðə skaɪ tə kip mɛmɹiz ə ðə stɛɾɪŋ fɹɛʃ." hɪz tʃɛɹ ɡɹoʊn əz i ʃɪftəd fɔɹwɝd, dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ wɪð ɪz hænz, wʌn ʌv wɪtʃ stɪl hɛl ðə bʊk. hɪz aɪz wɝ bɹaɪɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ, ən ɪz ɪɹz ɔlmoʊs kwɪvɝd. "moʊsli ðeɪ juz ðə tʃɹiz ə ðə læn ən ðə pleɪs. jə kænɑt meɪk ðə lænd ɡoʊ əɡɛnst ɪtsɛlf. nɑt fəɹ lɔŋ; ðə lænd wɪl ɹəbɛl. jə mʌst ʃeɪp ðə vɪʒən tə ðə lænd, nɑt ðə læn tə ðə vɪʒən. ɪn ɛvɹi ɡɹoʊv wɑz plæntəɾ ɛvɹi tʃɹi ðət wəd ɡɹoʊ ən θɹaɪv ɪn ðət pleɪs, itʃ bælənst əɡɛns ðə nɛkst, itʃ pleɪs tə kɑmpləmən ði ʌðɝz, fəɹ ðə bɛst ɡɹoʊɪŋ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɔlsoʊ soʊ ðət ðə bæləns wəd sɪŋ ɪn ði aɪ ən ðə hɑɹt. ɑ, ðə bʊks spoʊk ʌv ɡɹoʊvz tə meɪk ɛldɝz wip ən læf ət ðə seɪm taɪm, ɡɹoʊvz tə ɹɪmeɪn ɡɹin ɪn mɛmɹi fɝɛvɝ."

"Yes, the groves. The trees. Only a few of the Great Trees, of course, towering to the sky to keep memories of the stedding fresh." His chair groaned as he shifted forward, gesturing with his hands, one of which still held the book. His eyes were brighter than ever, and his ears almost quivered. "Mostly they used the trees of the land and the place. You cannot make the land go against itself. Not for long; the land will rebel. You must shape the vision to the land, not the land to the vision. In every grove was planted every tree that would grow and thrive in that place, each balanced against the next, each placed to complement the others, for the best growing, of course, but also so that the balance would sing in the eye and the heart. Ah, the books spoke of groves to make Elders weep and laugh at the same time, groves to remain green in memory forever."

"wʌɾ əbaʊt ðə sɪɾiz?" ɹænd æskt. lɔɪəl ɡeɪv ɪm ə pʌzəld lʊk. "ðə sɪɾiz. ðə sɪɾiz ði oʊɡiɝ bɪlt. hɪɹ, fəɹ ɪnstəns. keɪɛmlɪn. oʊɡiɝ bɪl keɪɛmlɪn, dɪdn ju? ðə stɔɹiz seɪ soʊ."

"What about the cities?" Rand asked. Loial gave him a puzzled look. "The cities. The cities the Ogier built. Here, for instance. Caemlyn. Ogier built Caemlyn, didn't you? The stories say so."

"wɝkɪŋ wɪð stoʊn. . . ." hɪz ʃoʊldɝz ɡeɪv ə mæsɪv ʃɹʌɡ. "ðæt wɑz dʒʌst sʌmθɪŋ lɝn ɪn ðə jɪɹz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ, dʊɹɪŋ ði ɛɡzaɪl, wən wi wɝ stɪl tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ əɡɛn. ɪts ə faɪn θɪŋ, aɪ səpoʊz, bʌt nɑt ðə tʃɹu θɪŋ. tʃɹaɪ əz jəl - ən aɪ hæv ɹɛd ðət ði oʊɡiɝ u bɪl ðoʊz sɪɾiz tʃɹuli dɪd tʃɹaɪ - jə kænɑt meɪk stoʊn lɪv. ə fju stɪl də wɝk wɪð stoʊn, bʌɾ oʊnli kəz jə hjumənz dæmədʒ ðə bɪldɪŋz soʊ ɔfən wɪð jəɹ wɔɹz. ðəɹ wɝ ə hændfʊl ʌv oʊɡiɝ ɪn . . . ɑ . . . kɛɹhin, ɪts kɔl naʊ . . . wən aɪ pæs θɹu. ðeɪ wɝ fɹəm ənʌðɝ stɛɾɪŋ, lʌkəli, soʊ ðeɪ dɪdnt noʊ əbaʊt mi, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ stɪl səspɪʃəs ðəɾ aɪ wɑz aʊtsaɪɾ əloʊn soʊ jʌŋ. aɪ səpoʊz ɪts dʒʌst əz wɛl ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɹizən fəɹ mi tə lɪŋɡɝ ðɛɹ. ɪn ɛni keɪs, jə si, wɝkɪŋ wɪð stoʊn ɪz dʒʌst sʌmθɪŋ ðət wɑz θɹʌst ɑn əs baɪ ðə wivɪŋ ə ðə pæɾɝn; ðə ɡɹoʊvz keɪm fɹəm ðə hɑɹt."

"Working with stone. . . ." His shoulders gave a massive shrug. "That was just something learned in the years after the Breaking, during the Exile, when we were still trying to find the stedding again. It is a fine thing, I suppose, but not the true thing. Try as you will - and I have read that the Ogier who built those cities truly did try - you cannot make stone live. A few still do work with stone, but only because you humans damage the buildings so often with your wars. There were a handful of Ogier in . . . ah . . . Cairhien, it's called now . . . when I passed through. They were from another stedding, luckily, so they didn't know about me, but they were still suspicious that I was Outside alone so young. I suppose it's just as well there was no reason for me to linger there. In any case, you see, working with stone is just something that was thrust on us by the weaving of the Pattern; the groves came from the heart."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hæf ðə stɔɹiz i hæd ɡɹoʊn ʌp wɪð hæd dʒʌs bɪn stʊɾ ɑn ðɛɹ hɛdz. "aɪ dɪdnt noʊ oʊɡiɝ bɪlivd ɪn ðə pæɾɝn, lɔɪəl."

Rand shook his head. Half the stories he had grown up with had just been stood on their heads. "I didn't know Ogier believed in the Pattern, Loial."

"ʌv kɔɹs, wi bɪliv. ðə wil ə taɪm wivz ðə pæɾɝn ə ði eɪdʒəz, ən laɪvz ɑɹ ðə θɹɛdz ɪt wivz. noʊ wʌn kən tɛl haʊ ðə θɹɛɾ ə hɪz oʊn laɪf wɪl bi woʊvən ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn, əɹ haʊ ðə θɹɛɾ ʌv ə pipəl wɪl bi woʊvən. ɪt ɡeɪv əs ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ən ði ɛɡzaɪl, ən stoʊn, ən ðə lɔŋɪŋ, ən ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɪt ɡeɪv əs bæk ðə stɛɾɪŋ bɪfɔɹ wi ɔl daɪd. səmtaɪmz aɪ θɪŋk ðə ɹizən jə hjumənz ɑɹ ðə weɪ jə ɑɹ ɪz kəz jəɹ θɹɛdz ɑɹ soʊ ʃɔɹt. ðeɪ mʌs dʒʌmp ɝaʊn ɪn ðə wivɪŋ. oʊ, ðɛɹ, aɪv dʌn ɪɾ əɡɛn. ði ɛldɝz seɪ jə hjumənz doʊn laɪk tə bi ɹimaɪndəɾ ə haʊ ʃɔɹɾ ə taɪm jə laɪv. aɪ hoʊp aɪ dɪdn hɝt jəɹ filɪŋz."

"Of course, we believe. The Wheel of Time weaves the Pattern of the Ages, and lives are the threads it weaves. No one can tell how the thread of his own life will be woven into the Pattern, or how the thread of a people will be woven. It gave us the Breaking of the World, and the Exile, and Stone, and the Longing, and eventually it gave us back the stedding before we all died. Sometimes I think the reason you humans are the way you are is because your threads are so short. They must jump around in the weaving. Oh, there, I've done it again. The Elders say you humans don't like to be reminded of how short a time you live. I hope I didn't hurt your feelings."

ɹænd læft ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "nɑɾ əɾ ɔl. aɪ səpoʊz ɪɾəd bi fʌn tə lɪv əz lɔŋ əz jə du, bʌɾ aɪ nɛvɝ ɹɪli θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt. aɪ ɡɛs ɪf aɪ lɪv əz lɔŋ əz oʊl sɛn bui, ðæɾəl bi lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛnibəɾi."

Rand laughed and shook his head. "Not at all. I suppose it'd be fun to live as long as you do, but I never really thought about it. I guess if I live as long as old Cenn Buie, that'll be long enough for anybody."

"hi ɪz ə vɛɹi oʊl mæn?"

"He is a very old man?"

ɹænd dʒʌs nɑɾəd. hi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə ɪkspleɪn ðəɾ oʊl sɛn bui wɑz nɑt kwaɪɾ əz oʊld əz lɔɪəl.

Rand just nodded. He was not about to explain that old Cenn Buie was not quite as old as Loial.

"wɛl," lɔɪəl sɛd, "pɝhæps jə hjumənz də hæv ʃɔɹt laɪvz, bʌt jə də soʊ mʌtʃ wɪð ðɛm, ɔlweɪz dʒʌmpɪŋ ɝaʊnd, ɔlweɪz soʊ heɪsti. ən juv ðə hoʊl wɝl tə də ɪɾ ɪn. wi oʊɡiɝ ɑɹ baʊn tə əɹ stɛɾɪŋ."

"Well," Loial said, "perhaps you humans do have short lives, but you do so much with them, always jumping around, always so hasty. And you have the whole world to do it in. We Ogier are bound to our stedding."

"jɔɹ aʊtsaɪd."

"You're Outside."

"fɔɹ ə taɪm, ɹænd. bʌɾ aɪ mʌst ɡoʊ bæk, ɪvɛntʃəwəli. ðɪs wɝld ɪz jʊɹz, jʊɹz ən jəɹ kaɪnz. ðə stɛɾɪŋ ɑɹ maɪn. ðɛɹz tu mʌtʃ hɝli-bɝli aʊtsaɪd. ən soʊ mʌtʃ ɪz tʃeɪnʒd fɹəm wʌɾ aɪ ɹɛɾ əbaʊt."

"For a time, Rand. But I must go back, eventually. This world is yours, yours and your kind's. The stedding are mine. There's too much hurly-burly Outside. And so much is changed from what I read about."

"wɛl, θɪŋz də tʃeɪnʒ oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz. sʌm, ɛniweɪ."

"Well, things do change over the years. Some, anyway."

"sʌm? hæf ðə sɪɾiz aɪ ɹɛɾ əbaʊɾ ɑɹən ivən ðəɹ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ, ən moʊst ə ðə ɹɛst ɑɹ noʊn baɪ dɪfɹənt neɪmz. jə teɪk kɛɹhin. ðə sɪɾiz pɹɑpɝ neɪm ɪz ɑlkɛɹəhinælən, hɪl ə ðə ɡoʊldən dɔn. ðeɪ doʊn ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝ, fəɹ ɔl ə ðə sʌnɹaɪz ɑn ðɛɹ bænɝz. ən ðə ɡɹoʊv ðɛɹ. aɪ daʊɾ ɪf ɪts bɪn tɛndəd sɪns ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. ɪts dʒʌst ənʌðɝ fɔɹəst, naʊ, wɛɹ ðeɪ kʌt faɪɝwʊd. ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz ɑɹ ɔl ɡɔn, ən noʊ wʌn ɹɪmɛmbɝz ðɛm. ən hɪɹ? keɪɛmlɪn ɪz stɪl keɪɛmlɪn, bʌt ðeɪ lɛt ðə sɪɾi ɡɹoʊ ɹaɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə ɡɹoʊv. wɝ nɑɾ ə kɔɹɾɝ ʌv ə maɪl fɹəm ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ɪt ɹaɪt wɛɹ wi sɪt - fɹəm wɛɹ ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ɪt ʃəd bi. nɑɾ ə tʃɹi ʌv ɪt lɛft. aɪv bɪn tə tɛɹ ən ɪljən, tu. dɪfɹənt neɪmz, ən noʊ mɛmɹiz. ðɛɹz oʊnli pæstʃɝ fəɹ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz wɛɹ ðə ɡɹoʊv wɑz ət tiɹ, ən əɾ ɪljən ðə ɡɹoʊv ɪz ðə kɪŋz pɑɹk, wɛɹ i hʌns ɪz dɪɹ, ən nʌn əlaʊɾ ɪnsaɪd wɪθaʊɾ ɪz pɝmɪʃən. ɪts ɔl tʃeɪnʒd, ɹænd. aɪ fɪɹ vɛɹi mʌtʃ ðəɾ əl faɪn ðə seɪm ɛvɹiwɛɹ aɪ ɡoʊ. ɔl ðə ɡɹoʊvz ɡɔn, ɔl ðə mɛmɹiz ɡɔn, ɔl ðə dʒɹimz dɛd."

"Some? Half the cities I read about aren't even there any longer, and most of the rest are known by different names. You take Cairhien. The city's proper name is Al'cair'rahienallen, Hill of the Golden Dawn. They don't even remember, for all of the sunrise on their banners. And the grove there. I doubt if it has been tended since the Trolloc Wars. It's just another forest, now, where they cut firewood. The Great Trees are all gone, and no one remembers them. And here? Caemlyn is still Caemlyn, but they let the city grow right over the grove. We're not a quarter of a mile from the center of it right where we sit - from where the center of it should be. Not a tree of it left. I've been to Tear and Illian, too. Different names, and no memories. There's only pasture for their horses where the grove was at Tear, and at Illian the grove is the King's park, where he hunts his deer, and none allowed inside without his permission. It has all changed, Rand. I fear very much that I will find the same everywhere I go. All the groves gone, all the memories gone, all the dreams dead."

"ju kænt ɡɪv ʌp, lɔɪəl. jə kæn ɛvɝ ɡɪv ʌp. ɪf jə ɡɪv ʌp, jə maɪɾ əz wɛl bi dɛd." ɹænd sæŋk bæk ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ əz fɑɹ əz i kəd ɡoʊ, hɪz feɪs tɝnɪŋ ɹɛd. hi ɪkspɛktəd ði oʊɡiɝ tə læf ət hɪm, bʌt lɔɪəl nɑɾəd ɡɹeɪvli ɪnstɛd.

"You can't give up, Loial. You can't ever give up. If you give up, you might as well be dead." Rand sank back in his chair as far as he could go, his face turning red. He expected the Ogier to laugh at him, but Loial nodded gravely instead.

"jɛs, ðæts ðə weɪ ʌv jəɹ kaɪnd, ɪzən ɪt?" ði oʊɡiɝz vɔɪs tʃeɪnʒd, əz ɪf i wɝ kwoʊɾɪŋ sʌmθɪŋ. "tɪl ʃeɪɾ ɪz ɡɔn, tɪl wɔɾɝ ɪz ɡɔn, ɪndə ðə ʃædoʊ wɪð tiθ bɛɹd, skɹimɪŋ dɪfaɪəns wɪð ðə læs bɹɛθ, tə spɪɾ ɪn saɪtblɪndɝz aɪ ɑn ðə læs deɪ." lɔɪəl kɑkt ɪz ʃæɡi hɛɾ ɪkspɛktənli, bʌt ɹænd hæd noʊ aɪdiə wʌɾ ɪt wɑz i ɪkspɛktəd.

"Yes, that's the way of your kind, isn't it?" The Ogier's voice changed, as if he were quoting something. "Till shade is gone, till water is gone, into the Shadow with teeth bared, screaming defiance with the last breath, to spit in Sightblinder's eye on the Last Day." Loial cocked his shaggy head expectantly, but Rand had no idea what it was he expected.

ə mɪnət wɛn baɪ wɪð lɔɪəl weɪɾɪŋ, ðən ənʌðɝ, ən ɪz lɔŋ aɪbɹaʊz bɪɡæn tə dʒɹɔ daʊn ɪn pʌzəlmənt. bʌɾ i stɪl weɪɾəd, ðə saɪləns ɡɹoʊɪŋ ənkʌmftəɹbəl fəɹ ɹænd.

A minute went by with Loial waiting, then another, and his long eyebrows began to draw down in puzzlement. But he still waited, the silence growing uncomfortable for Rand.

"ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz," ɹænd sɛd faɪnəli, dʒʌs fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə bɹeɪk ðət saɪləns. "ɑɹ ðeɪ laɪk ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə?"

"The Great Trees," Rand said finally, just for something to break that silence. "Are they like Avendesora?"

lɔɪəl sæɾ ʌp ʃɑɹpli; hɪz tʃɛɹ skwild ən kɹæk soʊ laʊdli ɹænd θɔɾ ɪt wɑz gɑnə kʌm əpɑɹt. "ju noʊ bɛɾɝ ðən ðæt. ju, ʌv ɔl pipəl."

Loial sat up sharply; his chair squealed and cracked so loudly Rand thought it was going to come apart. "You know better than that. You, of all people."

"mi? haʊ wəɾ aɪ noʊ?"

"Me? How would I know?"

"ɑɹ jə pleɪɪŋ ə dʒoʊk ɑn mi? səmtaɪmz jə ilmɛn θɪŋk ði ɑɾəst θɪŋz ɑɹ fʌni."

"Are you playing a joke on me? Sometimes you Aielmen think the oddest things are funny."

"wʌt? aɪm nɑɾ ən ilmən! aɪm fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. aɪ nɛvɝ ivən sɔ ən ilmən!"

"What? I'm not an Aielman! I'm from the Two Rivers. I never even saw an Aielman!"

lɔɪəl ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ən ðə tʌfs ɑn ɪz ɪɹz dʒɹupt aʊtwɝd. "ju si? ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪz tʃeɪnʒd, ən hæf ʌv wʌɾ aɪ noʊ ɪz jusləs. aɪ hoʊp aɪ dɪd nɑɾ əfɛn ju. aɪm ʃʊɹ jəɹ tu ɹɪvɝz ɪz ə vɛɹi faɪn pleɪs, wɛɹɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz."

Loial shook his head, and the tufts on his ears drooped outward. "You see? Everything is changed, and half of what I know is useless. I hope I did not offend you. I'm sure your Two Rivers is a very fine place, wherever it is."

"sʌmbɑɾi toʊl mi," ɹænd sɛd, "ðæɾ ɪt wɑz wʌns kɔl meɪnɛðɝən. aɪd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ɪt, bʌt meɪbi ju. . . ."

"Somebody told me," Rand said, "that it was once called Manetheren. I'd never heard it, but maybe you. . . ."

ði oʊɡiɝz ɪɹz hæd pɝkt ʌp hæpəli. "ɑ! jɛs. meɪnɛðɝən." ðə tʌfs wɛn daʊn əɡɛn. "ðɛɹ wɑz ə vɛɹi faɪn ɡɹoʊv ðɛɹ. jəɹ peɪn sɪŋz ɪn maɪ hɑɹt, ɹænd ælθɹ. wi kəd nɑt kʌm ɪn taɪm."

The Ogier's ears had perked up happily. "Ah! Yes. Manetheren." The tufts went down again. "There was a very fine grove there. Your pain sings in my heart, Rand al'Thor. We could not come in time."

lɔɪəl baʊd wɛɹ i sæt, ən ɹænd baʊd bæk. hi səspɛktəd lɔɪəl wəd bi hɝɾ ɪf i dɪd nɑt, wəd θɪŋk i wɑz ɹuɾ ət ðə list. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf lɔɪəl θɔɾ i hæd ðə seɪm sɔɹɾ ə mɛmɹiz ði oʊɡiɝ sim tə. ðə kɔɹnɝz ə lɔɪəlz maʊθ ən aɪz wɝ sɝɾənli tɝn daʊn əz ɪf i wɝ ʃɛɹɪŋ ðə peɪn ə ɹændz lɔs, dʒʌst əz ɪf ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ə meɪnɛðɝən wɝ nɑt sʌmθɪŋ ðət hæpən tu θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ, nɪɹ ɪnʌf, sʌmθɪŋ ðət ɹænd oʊnli nu əbaʊt kəz ə mɔɪɹeɪnz stɔɹi.

Loial bowed where he sat, and Rand bowed back. He suspected Loial would be hurt if he did not, would think he was rude at the least. He wondered if Loial thought he had the same sort of memories the Ogier seemed to. The corners of Loial's mouth and eyes were certainly turned down as if he were sharing the pain of Rand's loss, just as if the destruction of Manetheren were not something that happened two thousand years ago, near enough, something that Rand only knew about because of Moiraine's story.

æftɝ ə taɪm lɔɪəl saɪd. "ðə wil tɝnz," hi sɛd, "ænd noʊ wʌn noʊz ɪts tɝnɪŋ. bʌt juv kʌm ɔlmoʊst əz fɑɹ fɹəm jəɹ hoʊm əz aɪ hæv. ə vɛɹi kənsɪɾɝəbəl dɪstəns, əz θɪŋz ɑɹ naʊ. wən ðə weɪz wɝ fɹili oʊpən, ʌv kɔɹs - bʌt ðəɾ ɪz lɔŋ pæst. tɛl mi, wʌt bɹɪŋz jə soʊ fɑɹ? ɪz ðəɹ sʌmθɪŋ jə wɑnə si, tu?"

After a time Loial sighed. "The Wheel turns," he said, "and no one knows its turning. But you have come almost as far from your home as I have. A very considerable distance, as things are now. When the Ways were freely open, of course - but that is long past. Tell me, what brings you so far? Is there something you want to see, too?"

ɹænd oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə seɪ ðət ðeɪ hæd kʌm tə si ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən - ən i kəd nɑt seɪ ɪt. pɝhæps ɪt wɑz kəz lɔɪəl æktəɾ əz ɪf i wɝ noʊ oʊldɝ ðən ɹænd, naɪnti jɪɹz oʊld əɹ noʊ naɪnti jɪɹz oʊld. meɪbi fəɹ ən oʊɡiɝ naɪnti jɪɹz wɑz nɑɾ ɛni oʊldɝ ðən i wɑz. ɪt hæd bɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm sɪns i hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə ɹɪli tɔk tə ɛniwʌn əbaʊt wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ. ɔlweɪz ðə fɪɹ ðət ðeɪ maɪt bi dɑɹkfɹɛnz, əɹ θɪŋk i wɑz. mæt wɑz soʊ dʒɹɔn ɪn ɑn hɪmsɛlf, fiɾɪŋ ɪz fɪɹz ɑn ɪz oʊn səspɪʃənz, ðəɾ i wɑz noʊ ɡʊd fəɹ tɔkɪŋ. ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf tɛlɪŋ lɔɪəl əbaʊt wɪntɝnaɪt. nɑɾ ə veɪɡ stɔɹi əbaʊt dɑɹkfɹɛnz; ðə tʃɹuθ əbaʊt tʃɹɑləks bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪn ðə dɔɹ, ən ə feɪɾ ɑn ðə kwɔɹi ɹoʊd.

Rand opened his mouth to say that they had come to see the false Dragon - and he could not say it. Perhaps it was because Loial acted as if he were no older than Rand, ninety years old or no ninety years old. Maybe for an Ogier ninety years was not any older than he was. It had been a long time since he had been able to really talk to anyone about what was happening. Always the fear that they might be Darkfriends, or think he was. Mat was so drawn in on himself, feeding his fears on his own suspicions, that he was no good for talking. Rand found himself telling Loial about Winternight. Not a vague story about Darkfriends; the truth about Trollocs breaking in the door, and a Fade on the Quarry Road.

pɑɹɾ ə hɪm wɑz hɔɹəfaɪɾ ət wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf i wɝ tu pipəl, wʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊld ɪz tʌŋ waɪl ði ʌðɝ oʊnli fɛl ðə ɹɪlif ət biɪŋ eɪbəl tə tɛl ɪɾ ɔl faɪnəli. ðə ɹɪzʌlt wɑz ðəɾ i stʌmbəld ən stʌɾɝd ən dʒʌmpt ɝaʊn ɪn ðə stɔɹi. ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ən luzɪŋ ɪz fɹɛnz ɪn ðə naɪt, nɑt noʊɪŋ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ əlaɪv əɹ dɛd. ðə feɪɾ ɪn waɪtbɹɪdʒ, ən tɑm daɪɪŋ soʊ ðeɪ kəɾ ɪskeɪp. ðə feɪɾ ɪn bɛɹlən. dɑɹkfɹɛnz leɪɾɝ, haʊəl ɡoʊd, ən ðə bɔɪ hu wɑz əfɹeɪɾ ə ðɛm, ən ðə wʊmən u tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl mæt. ðə hæfmən aʊtsaɪd ðə ɡus ən kɹaʊn.

Part of him was horrified at what he was doing, but it was almost as if he were two people, one trying to hold his tongue while the other only felt the relief at being able to tell it all finally. The result was that he stumbled and stuttered and jumped around in the story. Shadar Logoth and losing his friends in the night, not knowing if they were alive or dead. The Fade in Whitebridge, and Thom dying so they could escape. The Fade in Baerlon. Darkfriends later, Howal Gode, and the boy who was afraid of them, and the woman who tried to kill Mat. The Halfman outside the Goose and Crown.

wən i stɑɹɾəd bæbəlɪŋ əbaʊt dʒɹimz, ivən ðə pɑɹɾ ə hɪm ðət wɑntəd tə tɔk fɛl ðə hækəlz ɹaɪzɪŋ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk. hi bɪɾ ɪz tʌŋ klæmpɪŋ ɪz tiθ ʃʌt. bɹiðɪŋ hɛvəli θɹu hɪz noʊz, hi wɑtʃt ði oʊɡiɝ wɛɹəli, hoʊpɪŋ i θɔɾ i hæd mɛnt naɪtmɛɹz. ðə laɪt nu ɪɾ ɔl saʊndəd laɪk ə naɪtmɛɹ, əɹ ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ɛniwʌn naɪtmɛɹz. meɪbi lɔɪəl wəd dʒʌs θɪŋk i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ mæd. meɪbi. . . .

When he started babbling about dreams, even the part of him that wanted to talk felt the hackles rising on the back of his neck. He bit his tongue clamping his teeth shut. Breathing heavily through his nose, he watched the Ogier warily, hoping he thought he had meant nightmares. The Light knew it all sounded like a nightmare, or enough to give anyone nightmares. Maybe Loial would just think he was going mad. Maybe. . . .

"tɑvɝən," lɔɪəl sɛd.

"Ta'veren," Loial said.

ɹænd blɪŋkt. "wʌt?"

Rand blinked. "What?"

"tɑvɝən." lɔɪəl ɹʌbd bɪhaɪn ə pɔɪntəɾ ɪɹ wɪð wʌn blʌn fɪŋɡɝ ən ɡeɪv ə lɪɾəl ʃɹʌɡ. "ɛldɝ heɪmən ɔlweɪz sɛɾ aɪ nɛvɝ lɪsənd, bʌt səmtaɪmz aɪ dɪd. səmtaɪmz, aɪ lɪsənd. jə noʊ haʊ ðə pæɾɝn ɪz woʊvən, ʌv kɔɹs?"

"Ta'veren." Loial rubbed behind a pointed ear with one blunt finger and gave a little shrug. "Elder Haman always said I never listened, but sometimes I did. Sometimes, I listened. You know how the Pattern is woven, of course?"

"aɪ nɛvɝ ɹɪli θɔɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt," hi sɛd sloʊli. "ɪt dʒʌst ɪz."

"I never really thought about it," he said slowly. "It just is."

"ʌm, jɛs, wɛl. nɑɾ ɪɡzækli. jə si, ðə wil ə taɪm wivz ðə pæɾɝn ə ði eɪdʒəz, ən ðə θɹɛdz ɪt jusəz ɑɹ lɪvz. ɪts nɑt fɪkst, ðə pæɾɝn, nɑɾ ɔlweɪz. ɪf ə mæn tʃɹaɪz tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə dɝɛkʃən ə hɪz laɪf ən ðə pæɾɝn əz ɹum fəɹ ɪt, ðə wil dʒʌst wivz ɑn ən teɪks ɪɾ ɪn. ðəɹ ɪz ɔlweɪz ɹum fəɹ smɔl tʃeɪnʒəz, bʌt səmtaɪmz ðə pæɾɝn sɪmpli woʊn æksɛpt ə bɪɡ tʃeɪnʒ, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ hɑɹd jə tʃɹaɪ. jə ʌndɝstænd?"

"Um, yes, well. Not exactly. You see, the Wheel of Time weaves the Pattern of the Ages, and the threads it uses are lives. It is not fixed, the Pattern, not always. If a man tries to change the direction of his life and the Pattern has room for it, the Wheel just weaves on and takes it in. There is always room for small changes, but sometimes the Pattern simply won't accept a big change, no matter how hard you try. You understand?"

ɹænd nɑɾəd. "aɪ kəd lɪv ɑn ðə fɑɹm əɹ ɪn ɛmənz fild, ən ðət wəd bi ə smɔl tʃeɪnʒ. ɪf aɪ wɑntəd tə bi ə kɪŋ, ðoʊ. . . ." hi læft, ən lɔɪəl ɡeɪv ə ɡɹɪn ðəɾ ɔlmoʊst splɪɾ ɪz feɪs ɪn tu. hɪz tiθ wɝ waɪt, ən əz bɹɔɾ əz tʃɪzəlz.

Rand nodded. "I could live on the farm or in Emond's Field, and that would be a small change. If I wanted to be a king, though. . . ." He laughed, and Loial gave a grin that almost split his face in two. His teeth were white, and as broad as chisels.

"jɛs, ðæts ɪt. bʌt səmtaɪmz ðə tʃeɪnʒ tʃuzəz ju, əɹ ðə wil tʃuzəz ɪt fəɹ ju. ən səmtaɪmz ðə wil bɛnz ə laɪf-θɹɛd, əɹ sɛvɹəl θɹɛdz, ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ ðəɾ ɔl ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ θɹɛdz ɑɹ fɔɹs tə swɝl ɝaʊn ɪt, ən ðoʊz fɔɹs ʌðɝ θɹɛdz, ən ðoʊz stɪl ʌðɝz, ən ɑn ən ɑn. ðət fɝs bɛndɪŋ tə meɪk ðə wɛb, ðəɾ ɪz tɑvɝən, ən ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ jə kən də tə tʃeɪnʒ ɪt, nɑɾ əntɪl ðə pæɾɝn ɪtsɛlf tʃeɪnʒəz. ðə wɛb - tæmɹəleɪlən, ɪts kɔld - kən læs fəɹ wiks, əɹ fəɹ jɪɹz. ɪt kən teɪk ɪn ə taʊn, əɹ ivən ðə hoʊl pæɾɝn. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ wɑz tɑvɝən. soʊ wɑz luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝ, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ, aɪ səpoʊz." hi lɛɾ aʊɾ ə bumɪŋ tʃʌkəl. "ɛldɝ heɪmən wəd bi pɹaʊɾ ə mi. hi ɔlweɪz dʒɹoʊn ɑn, ən ðə bʊks əbaʊt tʃɹævlɪŋ wɝ mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd lɪsən səmtaɪmz."

"Yes, that's it. But sometimes the change chooses you, or the Wheel chooses it for you. And sometimes the Wheel bends a life-thread, or several threads, in such a way that all the surrounding threads are forced to swirl around it, and those force other threads, and those still others, and on and on. That first bending to make the Web, that is ta'veren, and there is nothing you can do to change it, not until the Pattern itself changes. The Web - ta'maral'ailen, it's called - can last for weeks, or for years. It can take in a town, or even the whole Pattern. Artur Hawkwing was ta'veren. So was Lews Therin Kinslayer, for that matter, I suppose." He let out a booming chuckle. "Elder Haman would be proud of me. He always droned on, and the books about traveling were much more interesting, but I did listen sometimes."

"ðæts ɔl vɛɹi wɛl," ɹænd sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪ doʊn si wʌɾ ɪts tə də wɪð mi. ɪm ə ʃɛpɝd, nɑɾ ənʌðɝ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ. ən niðɝ ɪz mæt, əɹ pɛɹɪn. ɪts dʒʌst . . . ɹɪdɪkjələs."

"That's all very well," Rand said, "but I don't see what it has to do with me. I'm a shepherd, not another Artur Hawkwing. And neither is Mat, or Perrin. It's just . . . ridiculous."

"aɪ dɪdn seɪ jə wɝ, bʌɾ aɪ kəɾ ɔlmoʊs fil ðə pæɾɝn swɝl dʒʌs lɪsnɪŋ tə jə tɛl jəɹ teɪl, ən aɪ hæv noʊ tælən ðɛɹ. jə ɑɹ tɑvɝən, ɔl ɹaɪt. ju, ən meɪbi jəɹ fɹɛnz, tu." ði oʊɡiɝ pɔzd, ɹʌbɪŋ ðə bɹɪdʒ ə hɪz bɹɔd noʊz θɔtfəli. faɪnəli hi nɑɾəd tə hɪmsɛlf əz ɪf i hæd ɹitʃt ə dɪsɪʒən. "aɪ wɪʃ tə tʃɹævəl wɪð ju, ɹænd."

"I didn't say you were, but I could almost feel the Pattern swirl just listening to you tell your tale, and I have no Talent there. You are ta'veren, all right. You, and maybe your friends, too." The Ogier paused, rubbing the bridge of his broad nose thoughtfully. Finally he nodded to himself as if he had reached a decision. "I wish to travel with you, Rand."

fəɹ ə mɪnət ɹænd stɛɹd, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf i hæd hɝd kɝɛkli. "wɪð mi?" hi ɪkskleɪmd wən i kəd spik. "dɪdn jə hɪɹ wʌɾ aɪ sɛɾ əbaʊt . . . ?" hi aɪd ðə dɔɹ sʌɾənli. ɪt wɑz ʃʌt taɪt, ən θɪk ɪnʌf ðəɾ ɛniwʌn tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lɪsən ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd wəd hɪɹ oʊnli ə mɝmɝ, ivən wɪð ɪz ɪɹ pɹɛst əɡɛns ðə wʊɾən pænəlz. dʒʌs ðə seɪm i wɛn ɑn ɪn ə loʊɝ vɔɪs. "əbaʊt huz tʃeɪsɪŋ mi? ɛniweɪ, aɪ θɔt jə wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ si jəɹ tʃɹiz."

For a minute Rand stared, wondering if he had heard correctly. "With me?" he exclaimed when he could speak. "Didn't you hear what I said about . . . ?" He eyed the door suddenly. It was shut tight, and thick enough that anyone trying to listen on the other side would hear only a murmur, even with his ear pressed against the wooden panels. Just the same he went on in a lower voice. "About who's chasing me? Anyway, I thought you wanted to go see your trees."

"ðɛɹ ɪz ə vɛɹi faɪn ɡɹoʊv ət tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən aɪ hæv bɪn toʊl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kip ɪt wɛl tɛndəd. bɪsaɪdz, ɪts nɑt dʒʌs ðə ɡɹoʊvz aɪ wɑnə si. pɝhæps jə ɑɹ nɑɾ ənʌðɝ ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ, bʌt fəɹ ə taɪm, ət list, pɑɹɾ ə ðə wɝld wɪl ʃeɪp ɪtsɛlf ɝaʊn ju, pɝhæps ɪz ivən naʊ ʃeɪpɪŋ ɪtsɛlf ɝaʊn ju. ivən ɛldɝ heɪmən wəd wɑnə si ðæt."

"There is a very fine grove at Tar Valon, and I have been told the Aes Sedai keep it well tended. Besides, it is not just the groves I want to see. Perhaps you are not another Artur Hawkwing, but for a time, at least, part of the world will shape itself around you, perhaps is even now shaping itself around you. Even Elder Haman would want to see that."

ɹænd hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ɪt wəd bi ɡʊd tə hæv sʌmwʌn ɛls əlɔŋ. ðə weɪ mæt wɑz bɪheɪvɪŋ, biɪŋ wɪð ɪm wɑz ɔlmoʊs laɪk biɪŋ əloʊn. ði oʊɡiɝ wɑz ə kʌmfɝɾɪŋ pɹɛzəns. meɪbi hi wɑz jʌŋ əz oʊɡiɝ ɹɛkən eɪdʒ, bʌɾ i simd əz ənflæpəbəl əz ə ɹɑk, dʒʌs laɪk tæm. ən lɔɪəl hæd bɪn ɔl ə ðoʊz pleɪsəz, ən nu əbaʊɾ ʌðɝz. hi lʊkt ət ði oʊɡiɝ, sɪɾɪŋ ðəɹ wɪð ɪz bɹɔd feɪs ə pɪktʃɝ ə peɪʃəns. sɪɾɪŋ ðɛɹ, ən tɔlɝ sɪɾɪŋ ðən moʊs mɛn stændɪŋ. haʊ dʒju haɪd sʌmbɑɾi ɔlmoʊs tɛn fit tɔl? hi saɪɾ ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd.

Rand hesitated. It would be good to have someone else along. The way Mat was behaving, being with him was almost like being alone. The Ogier was a comforting presence. Maybe he was young as Ogier reckoned age, but he seemed as unflappable as a rock, just like Tam. And Loial had been all of those places, and knew about others. He looked at the Ogier, sitting there with his broad face a picture of patience. Sitting there, and taller sitting than most men standing. How do you hide somebody almost ten feet tall? He sighed and shook his head.

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ðəɾ ɪz ə ɡʊɾ aɪdiə, lɔɪəl. ivən ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn faɪnz əs hɪɹ, wɪl bi ɪn deɪnʒɝ ɔl ðə weɪ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. ɪf ʃi dʌz nɑt. . . ." ɪf ʃi dʌznt, ðən ʃiz dɛɾ ən soʊ ɪz ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. oʊ, ɛɡwin. hi ɡeɪv hɪmsɛlf ə ʃeɪk. ɛɡwin wɑz nɑt dɛd, ən mɔɪɹeɪn wəd faɪn ðɛm.

"I don't think that is a good idea, Loial. Even if Moiraine finds us here, we'll be in danger all the way to Tar Valon. If she does not. . . ." If she doesn't, then she's dead and so is everyone else. Oh, Egwene. He gave himself a shake. Egwene was not dead, and Moiraine would find them.

lɔɪəl lʊkt əɾ ɪm sɪmpəθɛɾɪkəli ən tʌtʃt ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "aɪ æm ʃʊɹ jəɹ fɹɛnz ɑɹ wɛl, ɹænd."

Loial looked at him sympathetically and touched his shoulder. "I am sure your friends are well, Rand."

ɹænd nɑɾəd ɪz θæŋks. hɪz θɹoʊt wɑz tu taɪt tə spik.

Rand nodded his thanks. His throat was too tight to speak.

"wɪl jə ət lis tɔk wɪð mi səmtaɪmz?" lɔɪəl saɪd, ə bæs ɹʌmbəl. "æn pɝhæps pleɪ ə ɡeɪm ə stoʊnz? aɪ hæv nɑt hæɾ ɛniwʌn tə tɔk tə ɪn deɪz, ɪksɛpt ɡʊd mæstɝ ɡɪl, ən hiz bɪzi moʊst ə ðə taɪm. ðə kʊk simz tə ɹʌn ɪm ənmɝsɪfəli. pɝhæps ʃi ɹɪli oʊnz ði ɪn?"

"Will you at least talk with me sometimes?" Loial sighed, a bass rumble. "And perhaps play a game of stones? I have not had anyone to talk to in days, except good Master Gill, and he is busy most of the time. The cook seems to run him unmercifully. Perhaps she really owns the inn?"

"ʌv kɔɹs, aɪ wɪl." hɪz vɔɪs wɑz hɔɹs. hi klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ən tʃɹaɪd tə ɡɹɪn. "æn ɪf wi miɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, jə kən ʃoʊ mi ðə ɡɹoʊv ðɛɹ." ðeɪv tə bi ɔl ɹaɪt. laɪt sɛn ðəɹ ɔl ɹaɪt.

"Of course, I will." His voice was hoarse. He cleared his throat and tried to grin. "And if we meet in Tar Valon, you can show me the grove there." They have to be all right. Light send they're all right.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾisɛvən


CHAPTER 37

ðə lɔŋ tʃeɪs


The Long Chase

nɪneɪiv ɡɹɪp ðə ɹeɪnz ə ðə θɹi hɔɹsəz ən pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə naɪɾ əz ɪf ʃi kəd sʌmhaʊ pɪɹs ðə dɑɹknəs ən faɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ. skɛləɾəl tʃɹiz sɝaʊndəd hɝ, stɑɹk ən blæk ɪn ðə dɪm munlaɪt. ðə tʃɹiz ən ðə naɪt meɪɾ ən ɪfɛktɪv skɹin fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn wɝ duɪŋ, nɑt ðəɾ iðɝ ə ðɛm hæd pɔz tə lɛɾ əɹ noʊ wʌt ðət wɑz. ə loʊ "kip ðə hɔɹsəz kwaɪət," fɹəm læn, ən ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn, livɪŋ əɹ stændɪŋ laɪk ə steɪbəlbɔɪ. ʃi ɡlænst ət ðə hɔɹsəz ən saɪd wɪð ɛksæspɝeɪʃən.

Nynaeve gripped the reins of the three horses and peered into the night as if she could somehow pierce the darkness and find the Aes Sedai and the Warder. Skeletal trees surrounded her, stark and black in the dim moonlight. The trees and the night made an effective screen for Whatever Moiraine and Lan were doing, not that either of them had paused to let her know what that was. A low "Keep the horses quiet," from Lan, and they were gone, leaving her standing like a stableboy. She glanced at the horses and sighed with exasperation.

mændɑɹb blɛndəɾ ɪndə ðə naɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əz wɛl əz ɪz mæstɝz kloʊk. ði oʊnli ɹizən ðə bæɾəl-tʃɹeɪnd stæljən wɑz lɛɾɪŋ əɹ ɡɛt ðɪs kloʊs wɑz kəz læn hæd hændəɾ əɹ ðə ɹeɪnz hɪmsɛlf. hi sim kɑm ɪnʌf naʊ, bʌt ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɔl tu wɛl ðə lɪps dʒɹɔɪŋ bæk saɪlənli wən ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ ɪz bɹaɪɾəl wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ lænz əpɹuvəl. ðə saɪləns hæd meɪd ðə bɛɹd tiθ sim ðət mʌtʃ mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs. wɪð ə læst wɛɹi lʊk ət ðə stæljən, ʃi tɝn tə pɪɹ ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ði ʌðɝ tu hæd ɡɔn, aɪdli stʃɹoʊkɪŋ əɹ oʊn hɔɹs. ʃi ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾəld dʒʌmp wən ɑldib pʊʃt ə peɪl mʌzəl ʌndɝ əɹ hænd, bʌɾ æftɝ ə mɪnət ʃi ɡeɪv ðə waɪt mɛɹ ə pæt, tu.

Mandarb blended into the night almost as well as his master's cloak. The only reason the battle-trained stallion was letting her get this close was because Lan had handed her the reins himself. He seemed calm enough now, but she remembered all too well the lips drawing back silently when she reached for his bridle without waiting for Lan's approval. The silence had made the bared teeth seem that much more dangerous. With a last wary look at the stallion, she turned to peer in the direction the other two had gone, idly stroking her own horse. She gave a startled jump when Aldieb pushed a pale muzzle under her hand, but after a minute she gave the white mare a pat, too.

"noʊ nid tə teɪk ɪɾ aʊɾ ɑn ju, aɪ səpoʊz," ʃi wɪspɝd, "dʒʌs kəz jəɹ mɪstʃɹəs ɪz ə koʊld-feɪst - " ʃi stʃɹeɪn ət ðə dɑɹknəs əɡɛn. wʌt wɝ ðeɪ duɪŋ?

"No need to take it out on you, I suppose," she whispered, "just because your mistress is a cold-faced - " She strained at the darkness again. What were they doing?

æftɝ livɪŋ waɪtbɹɪdʒ ðeɪ hæd ɹɪɾən θɹu vɪlədʒəz ðət simd ənɹil ɪn ðɛɹ nɔɹmæləɾi, ɔɹɾənɛɹi mɑɹkət vɪlədʒəz ðət sim tə nɪneɪiv ʌnkənɛktɪd tə ə wɝl ðət hæd feɪdz ən tʃɹɑləks ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðeɪ hæd fɑloʊd ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd, əntɪl ət læs mɔɪɹeɪn sæt fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ɑldibz sæɾəl, piɹɪŋ istwɝɾ əz ɪf ʃi kəd si ðə hoʊl lɛŋθ ə ðə ɡɹeɪt haɪweɪ, ɔl ðə mɛni maɪlz tə keɪɛmlɪn, ən si, tu, wʌt weɪɾəd ðɛɹ.

After leaving Whitebridge they had ridden through villages that seemed unreal in their normality, ordinary market villages that seemed to Nynaeve unconnected to a world that had Fades and Trollocs and Aes Sedai. They had followed the Caemlyn Road, until at last Moiraine sat forward in Aldieb's saddle, peering eastward as if she could see the whole length of the great highway, all the many miles to Caemlyn, and see, too, what waited there.

ɪvɛntʃəwəli ði ɛɛs sədaɪ lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ ən sɛɾəld bæk. "ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz," ʃi mɝmɝd, "bʌɾ aɪ kænɑt bɪliv ɪt wivz ən ɛn tə hoʊp. aɪ mʌs fɝs teɪk kɛɹ ə ðəɾ ʌv wɪtʃ aɪ kən bi sɝɾən. ɪɾəl bi əz ðə wil wivz." ən ʃi tɝn əɹ mɛɹ nɔɹθ, ɔf ðə ɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst. wʌn ə ðə bɔɪz wɑz ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən wɪð ðə kɔɪn mɔɪɹeɪn hæd ɡɪvən hɪm. læn fɑloʊd.

Eventually the Aes Sedai let out a long breath and settled back. "The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills," she murmured, "but I cannot believe it weaves an end to hope. I must first take care of that of which I can be certain. It will be as the Wheel weaves." And she turned her mare north, off the road into the forest. One of the boys was in that direction with the coin Moiraine had given him. Lan followed.

nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ə lɔŋ læs lʊk ət ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd. fju pipəl ʃɛɹd ðə ɹoʊdweɪ wɪð əm ðɛɹ, ə kʌpəl ə haɪ-wil kɑɹts ən wʌn ɛmpti wæɡən ɪn ðə dɪstəns, ə hændfʊl ə foʊk əfʊt wɪð ðɛɹ bɪlɔŋɪŋz ɑn ðɛɹ bæks əɹ paɪld ɑn pʊʃkɑɹts. səm ə ðoʊz wɝ wɪlɪŋ tə ədmɪt ðeɪ wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn tə si ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən, bʌt moʊs dɪnaɪɾ ɪt viəmənli, ɪspɛʃli ðoʊz u hæd kʌm θɹu waɪtbɹɪdʒ. ət waɪtbɹɪdʒ ʃi hæd bɪɡʌn tə bɪliv mɔɪɹeɪn. sʌmwʌt. mɔɹ, əɾ ɛni ɹeɪt. ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ kʌmfɝɾ ɪn ðæt.

Nynaeve gave a long last look at the Caemlyn Road. Few people shared the roadway with them there, a couple of high-wheeled carts and one empty wagon in the distance, a handful of folk afoot with their belongings on their backs or piled on pushcarts. Some of those were willing to admit they were on their way to Caemlyn to see the false Dragon, but most denied it vehemently, especially those who had come through Whitebridge. At Whitebridge she had begun to believe Moiraine. Somewhat. More, at any rate. And there was no comfort in that.

ðə wɔɹɾɝ ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝ ɔlmoʊst aʊɾ ə saɪt θɹu ðə tʃɹiz bɪfɔɹ ʃi stɑɹɾəd æftɝ ðɛm. ʃi hɝid tə kætʃ ʌp. læn lʊk bæk əɾ əɹ fɹikwənli, ən weɪv fəɹ əɹ tə kʌm ɑn, bʌɾ i kɛpt ət mɔɪɹeɪnz ʃoʊldɝ, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæɾ əɹ aɪz fɪkst əhɛd.

The Warder and the Aes Sedai were almost out of sight through the trees before she started after them. She hurried to catch up. Lan looked back at her frequently, and waved for her to come on, but he kept at Moiraine's shoulder, and the Aes Sedai had her eyes fixed ahead.

wʌn ivnɪŋ æftɝ ðeɪ lɛf ðə ɹoʊd, ði ɪnvɪzəbəl tʃɹeɪl feɪld. mɔɪɹeɪn, ði ənflæpəbəl mɔɪɹeɪn, sʌɾənli stʊɾ ʌp bɪsaɪd ðə smɔl faɪɝ wɛɹ ðə ti kɛɾəl wɑz bɔɪlɪŋ, hɝ aɪz waɪɾənɪŋ. "ɪɾ ɪz ɡɔn," ʃi wɪspɝɾ ət ðə naɪt.

One evening after they left the road, the invisible trail failed. Moiraine, the unflappable Moiraine, suddenly stood up beside the small fire where the tea kettle was boiling, her eyes widening. "It is gone," she whispered at the night.

"hi ɪz . . . ?" nɪneɪiv kəd nɑt fɪnɪʃ ðə kwɛstʃən. laɪt, aɪ doʊn ivən noʊ wɪtʃ wʌn ɪɾ ɪz!

"He is . . . ?" Nynaeve could not finish the question. Light, I don't even know which one it is!

"hi dɪd nɑt daɪ," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd sloʊli, "bʌɾ i noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əz ðə toʊkən." ʃi sæt daʊn, hɝ vɔɪs lɛvəl ən əɹ hænz stɛɾi əz ʃi tʊk ðə kɛɾəl ɔf ðə fleɪmz ən tɔst ɪn ə hændfʊl ə ti. "ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wɪl kip ɑn əz wiv bɪn ɡoʊɪŋ. wən aɪ ɡɛt kloʊs ɪnʌf, aɪ kən faɪn ɪm wɪθaʊt ðə kɔɪn."

"He did not die," the Aes Sedai said slowly, "but he no longer has the token." She sat down, her voice level and her hands steady as she took the kettle off the flames and tossed in a handful of tea. "In the morning we will keep on as we've been going. When I get close enough, I can find him without the coin."

əz ðə faɪɝ bɝn daʊn tə koʊlz, læn ɹoʊl hɪmsɛlf ɪn ɪz kloʊk ən wɛn tə slip. nɪneɪiv kəd nɑt slip. ʃi wɑtʃt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. mɔɪɹeɪn hæɾ əɹ aɪz kloʊzd, bʌt ʃi sæɾ əpɹaɪt, ən nɪneɪiv nu ʃi wɑz əweɪk.

As the fire burned down to coals, Lan rolled himself in his cloak and went to sleep. Nynaeve could not sleep. She watched the Aes Sedai. Moiraine had her eyes closed, but she sat upright, and Nynaeve knew she was awake.

lɔŋ æftɝ ðə læst ɡloʊ hæd feɪɾəd fɹəm ðə koʊlz, mɔɪɹeɪn oʊpən əɹ aɪz ən lʊkt ət hɝ. ʃi kəd fil ði ɛɛs sədaɪz smaɪl ivən ɪn ðə dɑɹk. "hi hæz ɹiɡeɪn ðə kɔɪn, wɪzdəm. ɔl wɪl bi wɛl." ʃi leɪ daʊn ɑn əɹ blæŋkəts wɪð ə saɪ ən ɔlmoʊst ət wʌns wɑz bɹiðɪŋ dip ɪn slʌmbɝ.

Long after the last glow had faded from the coals, Moiraine opened her eyes and looked at her. She could feel the Aes Sedai's smile even in the dark. "He has regained the coin, Wisdom. All will be well." She lay down on her blankets with a sigh and almost at once was breathing deep in slumber.

nɪneɪiv hæɾ ə hɑɹd taɪm dʒɔɪnɪŋ hɝ, taɪɝɾ əz ʃi wɑz. hɝ maɪn kɑnʒɝd ʌp ðə wɝs noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ ʃi tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp ɪt. ɔl wɪl bi wɛl. æftɝ waɪtbɹɪdʒ, ʃi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ meɪk hɝsɛlf bɪliv ðət soʊ izəli.

Nynaeve had a hard time joining her, tired as she was. Her mind conjured up the worst no matter how she tried to stop it. All will be well. After Whitebridge, she could no longer make herself believe that so easily.

əbɹʌpli nɪneɪiv wɑz dʒɝk fɹəm mɛmɹi bæk tə ðə naɪt; ðəɹ ɹɪli wɑz ə hæn ɑn əɹ ɑɹm. staɪflɪŋ ðə kɹaɪ ðət ɹoʊz ɪn əɹ θɹoʊt, ʃi fʌmbəl fəɹ ðə naɪf əɾ əɹ bɛlt, hɝ hæn kloʊzɪŋ ɑn ðə hɪl bɪfɔɹ ʃi ɹilaɪz ðət ðə hænd wɑz lænz.

Abruptly Nynaeve was jerked from memory back to the night; there really was a hand on her arm. Stifling the cry that rose in her throat, she fumbled for the knife at her belt, her hand closing on the hilt before she realized that the hand was Lan's.

ðə wɔɹɾɝz hʊd wɑz θɹoʊn bæk, bʌɾ ɪz tʃəmɛliən-laɪk kloʊk blɛndəd soʊ wɛl wɪð ðə naɪt ðət ðə dɪm blɝ ə hɪz feɪs sim tə hæŋ səspɛndəɾ ɪn ðə naɪt. ðə hæn ɑn əɹ ɑɹm əpɪɹd tə kʌm aʊɾ ə θɪn ɛɹ.

The Warder's hood was thrown back, but his chameleon-like cloak blended so well with the night that the dim blur of his face seemed to hang suspended in the night. The hand on her arm appeared to come out of thin air.

ʃi dʒɹu ə ʃʌɾɝɪŋ bɹɛθ. ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪm tə kɑmɛn ɑn haʊ izəli hi hæd kʌm ɑn əɹ ʌnəwɛɹ, bʌɾ ɪnstɛɾ i tɝn tə dɪɡ ɪndə hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz. "ju ɑɹ niɾəd," hi sɛd, ən nɛl tə fæsən hɑbəlz ɑn ðə hɔɹsəz.

She drew a shuddering breath. She expected him to comment on how easily he had come on her unaware, but instead he turned to dig into his saddlebags. "You are needed," he said, and knelt to fasten hobbles on the horses.

əz sun əz ðə hɔɹsəz wɝ sɪkjʊɹd, hi stʃɹeɪɾənd, ɡɹæspt əɹ hænd, ən hɛɾəd ɔf ɪndə ðə naɪɾ əɡɛn. hɪz dɑɹk hɛɹ fɪɾ ɪndə ðə naɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əz wɛl əz ɪz kloʊk, ən i meɪɾ ivən lɛs nɔɪz ðən ʃi dɪd. ɡɹʌdʒɪŋli ʃi hæd tə ədmɪt ðət ʃi kəd nɛvɝ əv fɑloʊɾ ɪm θɹu ðə dɑɹknəs wɪθaʊɾ ɪz ɡɹɪp əz ə ɡaɪd. ʃi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən ʃi kəd pʊl lus ɪf i dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɹilis hɝ, ɛniweɪ; hi hæd vɛɹi stʃɹɔŋ hænz.

As soon as the horses were secured, he straightened, grasped her hand, and headed off into the night again. His dark hair fit into the night almost as well as his cloak, and he made even less noise than she did. Grudgingly she had to admit that she could never have followed him through the darkness without his grip as a guide. She was not certain she could pull loose if he did not want to release her, anyway; he had very strong hands.

əz ðeɪ keɪm ʌp ɑn ə smɔl ɹaɪz, bɛɹli ɪnʌf tə bi kɔld ə hɪl, hi sæŋk tə wʌn ni, pʊlɪŋ əɹ daʊn bɪsaɪd hɪm. ɪt tʊk əɹ ə moʊmən tə si ðət mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ðɛɹ, tu. ənmoʊvɪŋ, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ cʊɾə pæs fəɹ ə ʃædoʊ ɪn əɹ dɑɹk kloʊk. læn dʒɛstʃɝd daʊn ðə hɪlsaɪd tə ə lɑɹdʒ klɪɹɪŋ ɪn ðə tʃɹiz.

As they came up on a small rise, barely enough to be called a hill, he sank to one knee, pulling her down beside him. It took her a moment to see that Moiraine was there, too. Unmoving, the Aes Sedai could have passed for a shadow in her dark cloak. Lan gestured down the hillside to a large clearing in the trees.

nɪneɪiv fɹaʊn ɪn ðə dɪm munlaɪt, ðən sʌɾənli smaɪld ɪn ʌndɝstændɪŋ. ðoʊz peɪl blɝz wɝ tɛns ɪn ɹɛɡjəlɝ ɹoʊz, ə dɑɹkən ɛnkæmpmənt.

Nynaeve frowned in the dim moonlight, then suddenly smiled in understanding. Those pale blurs were tents in regular rows, a darkened encampment.

"waɪtkloʊks," læn wɪspɝd, "tu hʌnʒɹəd ə ðɛm, meɪbi mɔɹ. ðɛɹz ɡʊd wɔɾɝ daʊn ðɛɹ. ən ðə læd wɝ æftɝ."

"Whitecloaks," Lan whispered, "two hundred of them, maybe more. There's good water down there. And the lad we're after."

"ɪn ðə kæmp?" ʃi fɛlt, mɔɹ ðən sɔ, læn nɑd.

"In the camp?" She felt, more than saw, Lan nod.

"ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪt. mɔɪɹeɪn kən pɔɪn ɹaɪt tə hɪm. aɪ wɛn kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si hiz ʌndɝ ɡɑɹd."

"In the middle of it. Moiraine can point right to him. I went close enough to see he's under guard."

"ə pɹɪznɝ?" nɪneɪiv sɛd. "waɪ?"

"A prisoner?" Nynaeve said. "Why?"

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ʃəd nɑt bi ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn ə vɪlədʒ bɔɪ, nɑɾ ənlɛs ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ tə meɪk əm səspɪʃəs. ðə laɪt noʊz ɪt dʌzn teɪk mʌtʃ tə meɪk waɪtkloʊks səspɪʃəs, bʌɾ ɪt stɪl wɝiz mi."

"I don't know. The Children should not be interested in a village boy, not unless there was something to make them suspicious. The Light knows it doesn't take much to make Whitecloaks suspicious, but it still worries me."

"haʊ ɑɹ jə gɑnə fɹi hɪm?" ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əntɪl i ɡlænst əɾ əɹ ðət ʃi ɹilaɪz haʊ mʌtʃ əʃʊɹəns ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɪn əɹ ðəɾ i kəd mɑɹtʃ ɪndə ðə mɪɾəl ə tu hʌnʒɹəd mɛn ən kʌm bæk wɪð ðə bɔɪ. wɛl, hiz ə wɔɹɾɝ. səm ə ðə stɔɹiz mʌs bi tʃɹu.

"How are you going to free him?" It was not until he glanced at her that she realized how much assurance there had been in her that he could march into the middle of two hundred men and come back with the boy. Well, he is a Warder. Some of the stories must be true.

ʃi wʌndɝɾ ɪf i wɑz læfɪŋ ət hɝ, bʌɾ ɪz vɔɪs wɑz flæɾ ən bɪznɪslaɪk. "aɪ kən bɹɪŋ ɪm aʊt, bʌt hɪl laɪkli bi ɪn noʊ ʃeɪp fəɹ stɛlθ. ɪf wɝ sin, wi meɪ faɪn tu hʌnʒɹəd waɪtkloʊks ɑn əɹ hilz, ən əs ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʌbəl. ənlɛs ðeɪ ɑɹ tu bɪzi tə tʃeɪs ʌs. ɑɹ jə wɪlɪŋ tə teɪk ə tʃæns?"

She wondered if he was laughing at her, but his voice was flat and businesslike. "I can bring him out, but he'll likely be in no shape for stealth. If we're seen, we may find two hundred Whitecloaks on our heels, and us riding double. Unless they are too busy to chase us. Are you willing to take a chance?"

"tə hɛlp ən ɛmənz fildɝ? ʌv kɔɹs! wʌt kaɪndə tʃæns?"

"To help an Emond's Fielder? Of course! What kind of chance?"

hi pɔɪntəɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs əɡɛn, bɪɑn ðə tɛns. ðɪs taɪm ʃi kəd meɪk aʊt nʌθɪŋ bʌt ʃædoʊz. "ðɛɹ hɔɹs-laɪnz. ɪf ðə pɪkət-ɹoʊps ɑɹ kʌt, nɑɾ ɔl ðə weɪ θɹu, bʌɾ ɪnʌf soʊ ðəl bɹeɪk wən mɔɪɹeɪn kɹieɪts ə daɪvɝʒən, ðə waɪtkloʊks wɪl bi tu bɪzi tʃeɪsɪŋ ðɛɹ oʊn hɔɹsəz tə kʌm æftɝ ʌs. ðəɹ ɑɹ tu ɡɑɹdz ɑn ðət saɪɾ ə ðə kæmp, bɪɑn ðə pɪkət-laɪnz, bʌɾ ɪf jə ɑɹ hæf əz ɡʊɾ əz aɪ θɪŋk jə ɑɹ, ðəl nɛvɝ si ju."

He pointed into the darkness again, beyond the tents. This time she could make out nothing but shadows. "Their horse-lines. If the picket-ropes are cut, not all the way through, but enough so they'll break when Moiraine creates a diversion, the Whitecloaks will be too busy chasing their own horses to come after us. There are two guards on that side of the camp, beyond the picket-lines, but if you are half as good as I think you are, they'll never see you."

ʃi swɑloʊd hɑɹd. stɔkɪŋ ɹæbəts wɑz wʌn θɪŋ; ɡɑɹdz, ðoʊ, wɪð spɪɹz ən sɔɹdz. . . . soʊ hi θɪŋks aɪm ɡʊd, dʌz hi? "aɪl də ɪt."

She swallowed hard. Stalking rabbits was one thing; guards, though, with spears and swords. . . . So he thinks I'm good, does he? "I'll do it."

læn nɑɾəd əɡɛn, əz ɪf i hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd noʊ lɛs. "wʌn ʌðɝ θɪŋ. ðəɹ ɑɹ wʊlvz əbaʊt, tənaɪt. aɪ sɔ tu, ən ɪf aɪ sɔ ðət mɛni, ðəɹ ɑɹ pɹɑbli mɔɹ." hi pɔzd, ən ðoʊ hɪz vɔɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ ʃi hæd ðə filɪŋ i wɑz pʌzəld. "ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf ðeɪ wɑntəd mi tə si ðɛm. ɛniweɪ, ðeɪ ʃʊdn bɑðɝ ju. wʊlvz juʒəwəli steɪ əweɪ fɹəm pipəl."

Lan nodded again, as if he had expected no less. "One other thing. There are wolves about, tonight. I saw two, and if I saw that many, there are probably more." He paused, and though his voice did not change she had the feeling he was puzzled. "It was almost as if they wanted me to see them. Anyway, they shouldn't bother you. Wolves usually stay away from people."

"aɪ wʊdn əv noʊn ðæt," ʃi sɛd switli. "aɪ oʊnli ɡɹu ʌp ɝaʊnd ʃɛpɝdz." hi ɡɹʌntɪd, ən ʃi smaɪld ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs.

"I wouldn't have known that," she said sweetly. "I only grew up around shepherds." He grunted, and she smiled into the darkness.

"wil də ɪt naʊ, ðɛn," hi sɛd.

"We'll do it now, then," he said.

hɝ smaɪl feɪɾəd əz ʃi pɪɹd daʊn ət ðə kæmp fʊl ʌv ɑɹmd mɛn. tu hʌnʒɹəd mɛn wɪð spɪɹz ən sɔɹdz ænd. . . . bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd ɹikənsɪɾɝ, ʃi izd əɹ naɪf ɪn ɪts ʃiθ ən stɑɹɾəd tə slɪp əweɪ. mɔɪɹeɪn kɑɾ əɹ ɑɹm ɪn ə ɡɹɪp ɔlmoʊst əz stʃɹɔŋ əz lænz.

Her smile faded as she peered down at the camp full of armed men. Two hundred men with spears and swords and. . . . Before she could reconsider, she eased her knife in its sheath and started to slip away. Moiraine caught her arm in a grip almost as strong as Lan's.

"teɪk kɛɹ," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd sɔfli. "wʌns jə kʌt ðə ɹoʊps, ɹɪtɝn əz kwɪkli əz jə kæn. jə ɑɹ ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn, tu, ən aɪ wəd nɑt ɹɪsk ju, ɛni mɔɹ ðən ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz, ɪf ðə hoʊl wɝld wɑz nɑɾ ət ɹɪsk ɪn ðiz deɪz."

"Take care," the Aes Sedai said softly. "Once you cut the ropes, return as quickly as you can. You are a part of the Pattern, too, and I would not risk you, any more than any of the others, if the whole world was not at risk in these days."

nɪneɪiv ɹʌbd əɹ ɑɹm sɝəptɪʃəsli wən mɔɪɹeɪn ɹilist ɪt. ʃi wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə lɛt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ noʊ ðə ɡɹɪp hæd hɝt. bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn tɝn bæk tə wɑtʃɪŋ ðə kæmp bɪloʊ əz sun əz ʃi lɛt ɡoʊ. ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz ɡɔn, nɪneɪiv ɹilaɪzd wɪð ə stɑɹt. ʃi hæd nɑt hɝɾ ɪm liv. laɪt blaɪn ðə blʌɾi mæn! kwɪkli ʃi taɪɾ əɹ skɝts ʌp tə ɡɪv əɹ lɛɡz fɹiɾəm, ən hɝiɾ ɪndə ðə naɪt.

Nynaeve rubbed her arm surreptitiously when Moiraine released it. She was not about to let the Aes Sedai know the grip had hurt. But Moiraine turned back to watching the camp below as soon as she let go. And the Warder was gone, Nynaeve realized with a start. She had not heard him leave. Light blind the bloody man! Quickly she tied her skirts up to give her legs freedom, and hurried into the night.

æftɝ ðət fɝst ɹʌʃ, wɪð fɔlən bɹæntʃəz kɹækɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ fit, ʃi sloʊd daʊn, ɡlæd ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wʌn ðəɹ tə si hɝ blʌʃ. ði aɪdiə wɑz tə bi kwaɪət, ən ʃi wɑz nɑɾ ɪn ɛni kaɪndə kɑmpətɪʃən wɪð ðə wɔɹɾɝ. oʊ, noʊ?

After that first rush, with fallen branches cracking under her feet, she slowed down, glad there was no one there to see her blush. The idea was to be quiet, and she was not in any kind of competition with the Warder. Oh, no?

ʃi ʃʊk ɔf ðə θɔɾ ən kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn meɪkɪŋ əɹ weɪ θɹu ðə dɑɹk wʊdz. ɪt wɑz nɑt hɑɹɾ ɪn ən ʌv ɪtsɛlf; ðə feɪn laɪɾ ə ðə weɪnɪŋ mun wɑz mɔɹ ðən ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛniwʌn u hæd bɪn tɔt baɪ hɝ fɑðɝ, ən ðə ɡɹaʊn hæɾ ə sloʊ, izi ɹoʊl. bʌt ðə tʃɹiz, bɛɹ ən stɑɹk əɡɛns ðə naɪt skaɪ, kɑnstənli ɹimaɪndəɾ əɹ ðət ðɪs wɑz noʊ tʃaɪldhʊd ɡeɪm, ən ðə kinɪŋ wɪn saʊndəɾ ɔl tu mʌtʃ laɪk tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹnz. naʊ ðət ʃi wɑz əloʊn ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, ʃi ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət ðə wʊlvz ðət juʒəwəli ɹæn əweɪ fɹəm pipəl hæd bɪn bɪheɪvɪŋ dɪfɹənli ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ðɪs wɪntɝ.

She shook off the thought and concentrated on making her way through the dark woods. It was not hard in and of itself; the faint light of the waning moon was more than enough for anyone who had been taught by her father, and the ground had a slow, easy roll. But the trees, bare and stark against the night sky, constantly reminded her that this was no childhood game, and the keening wind sounded all too much like Trolloc horns. Now that she was alone in the darkness, she remembered that the wolves that usually ran away from people had been behaving differently in the Two Rivers this winter.

ɹɪlif flʌɾəd θɹu hɝ laɪk wɔɹmθ wən ʃi faɪnəli kɑt ðə smɛl ə hɔɹsəz. ɔlmoʊs hoʊldɪŋ əɹ bɹɛθ, ʃi ɡɑt daʊn ɑn əɹ stʌmək ən kɹɔld ʌpwɪnd, təwɔɹd ðə smɛl.

Relief flooded through her like warmth when she finally caught the smell of horses. Almost holding her breath, she got down on her stomach and crawled upwind, toward the smell.

ʃi wɑz nɪɹli ɑn ðə ɡɑɹdz bɪfɔɹ ʃi sɔ ðɛm, mɑɹtʃɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə naɪt, waɪt kloʊks flæpɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪn ən ɔlmoʊst ʃaɪnɪŋ ɪn ðə munlaɪt. ðeɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl əv kæɹid tɔɹtʃɪz; tɔɹtʃlaɪt kəd nɑɾ əv meɪɾ əm mʌtʃ mɔɹ vɪzəbəl. ʃi fɹoʊz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk hɝsɛlf ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. nɪɹli ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, nɑt tɛn peɪsɪz əweɪ, ðeɪ mɑɹtʃt tə ə hɔlt wɪð ə stɑmp ə fit, feɪsɪŋ itʃ ʌðɝ, spɪɹz ʃoʊldɝd. dʒʌs bɪɑn əm ʃi kəd meɪk aʊt ʃædoʊz ðət hæd tə bi ðə hɔɹsəz. ðə steɪbəl smɛl, hɔɹs ən mənʊɹ, wɑz stʃɹɔŋ.

She was nearly on the guards before she saw them, marching toward her out of the night, white cloaks flapping in the wind and almost shining in the moonlight. They might as well have carried torches; torchlight could not have made them much more visible. She froze, trying to make herself a part of the ground. Nearly in front of her, not ten paces away, they marched to a halt with a stomp of feet, facing each other, spears shouldered. Just beyond them she could make out shadows that had to be the horses. The stable smell, horse and manure, was strong.

"ɔl ɪz wɛl wɪð ðə naɪt," wʌn waɪt-kloʊkt ʃeɪp ənaʊnst. "ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ʌs, ən pɹətɛkt əs fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊ."

"All is well with the night," one white-cloaked shape announced. "The Light illumine us, and protect us from the Shadow."

"ɔl ɪz wɛl wɪð ðə naɪt," ði ʌðɝ ɹɪplaɪd. "ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ʌs, ən pɹətɛkt əs fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊ."

"All is well with the night," the other replied. "The Light illumine us, and protect us from the Shadow."

wɪð ðət ðeɪ tɝn ən mɑɹtʃt ɔf ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs əɡɛn.

With that they turned and marched off into the darkness again.

nɪneɪiv weɪɾəd, kaʊntɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf waɪl ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ sɝkət twaɪs. itʃ taɪm ðeɪ tʊk ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm kaʊnt, ən itʃ taɪm ðeɪ ɹɪdʒɪdli ɹɪpiɾɪd ðə seɪm fɔɹmjələ, nɑɾ ə wɝd mɔɹ əɹ lɛs. niðɝ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ɡlæns tə wʌn saɪd; ðeɪ stɛɹd stʃɹeɪɾ əhɛɾ əz ðeɪ mɑɹtʃt ʌp, ðən mɑɹtʃt əweɪ. ʃi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðeɪ wʊɾə noʊɾəst əɹ ivən ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn stændɪŋ ʌp.

Nynaeve waited, counting to herself while they made their circuit twice. Each time they took exactly the same count, and each time they rigidly repeated the same formula, not a word more or less. Neither so much as glanced to one side; they stared straight ahead as they marched up, then marched away. She wondered if they would have noticed her even if she had been standing up.

bɪfɔɹ ðə naɪt swɑloʊd ðə peɪl swɝlz ə ðɛɹ kloʊks ə θɝd taɪm, ʃi wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn əɹ fit, ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn ə kɹaʊtʃ təwɔɹd ðə hɔɹsəz. əz ʃi keɪm kloʊs, ʃi sloʊd soʊ əz nɑt tə stɑɹɾəl ði ænəməlz. ðə waɪtkloʊk ɡɑɹdz maɪt nɑt si wʌt wɑz nɑt ʃʌvd ʌndɝ ðɛɹ noʊzɪz, bʌt ðeɪ wəd sɝɾənli ɪnvɛstəɡeɪɾ ɪf ðə hɔɹsəz sʌɾənli bɪɡæn wɪkɝɪŋ.

Before the night swallowed the pale swirls of their cloaks a third time, she was already on her feet, running in a crouch toward the horses. As she came close, she slowed so as not to startle the animals. The Whitecloak guards might not see what was not shoved under their noses, but they would certainly investigate if the horses suddenly began whickering.

ðə hɔɹsəz əlɔŋ ðə pɪkət-laɪnz - ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ ðən wʌn ɹoʊ - wɝ bɛɹli ɹilaɪz mæsəz ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs, hɛdz daʊn. əkeɪʒənəli wʌn snɔɹɾɪd əɹ stæmpt ə fʊɾ ɪn ɪts slip. ɪn ðə dɪm munlaɪt ʃi wɑz nɪɹli ɑn ði ɛndpoʊst ə ðə pɪkət-laɪn bɪfɔɹ ʃi sɔ ɪt. ʃi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə pɪkət-laɪn, ən fɹoʊz wən ðə nɪɹəs hɔɹs ɹeɪzd ɪts hɛɾ ən lʊkt ət hɝ. ɪts sɪŋɡəl lɛd-ɹeɪn wɑz taɪɾ ɪn ə bɪɡ lup ɝaʊn ðə θʌm-θɪk laɪn ðəɾ ɛndəɾ ət ðə poʊst. wʌn wɪni. hɝ hɑɹt tʃɹaɪd tə paʊn ɪts weɪ aʊɾ ə hɝ tʃɛst, saʊndɪŋ laʊɾ ɪnʌf tə bɹɪŋ ðə ɡɑɹdz.

The horses along the picket-lines - there was more than one row - were barely realized masses in the darkness, heads down. Occasionally one snorted or stamped a foot in its sleep. In the dim moonlight she was nearly on the endpost of the picket-line before she saw it. She reached for the picket-line, and froze when the nearest horse raised its head and looked at her. Its single lead-rein was tied in a big loop around the thumb-thick line that ended at the post. One whinny. Her heart tried to pound its way out of her chest, sounding loud enough to bring the guards.

nɛvɝ teɪkɪŋ əɹ aɪz ɔf ðə hɔɹs, ʃi slaɪst ət ðə pɪkət-ɹoʊp, filɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ bleɪd tə si haʊ fɑɹ ʃi hæd kʌt. ðə hɔɹs tɔst ɪts hɛd, ən əɹ bɹɛθ wɛn koʊld. dʒʌst wʌn wɪni.

Never taking her eyes off the horse, she sliced at the picket-rope, feeling in front of her blade to see how far she had cut. The horse tossed its head, and her breath went cold. Just one whinny.

oʊnli ə fju θɪn stʃɹænz ə hɛmp ɹɪmeɪn hoʊl ʌndɝ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. sloʊli ʃi hɛɾəd təwɔɹd ðə nɛks laɪn, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə hɔɹs əntɪl ʃi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ si ɪf ɪt wɑz lʊkɪŋ əɾ əɹ əɹ nɑt, ðən dʒɹu ə ɹæɡəd bɹɛθ. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɔl laɪk ðæt, ʃi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi wəd læst.

Only a few thin strands of hemp remained whole under her fingers. Slowly she headed toward the next line, watching the horse until she could no longer see if it was looking at her or not, then drew a ragged breath. If they were all like that, she did not think she would last.

ət ðə nɛks pɪkət-ɹoʊp, ðoʊ, ən ðə nɛkst, ən ðə nɛkst, ðə hɔɹsəz ɹɪmeɪn əslip, ivən wən ʃi kʌɾ əɹ θʌm ən bɪɾ ɔf ə jɛlp. sʌkɪŋ ðə kʌt, ʃi lʊkt wɛɹəli bæk ðə weɪ ʃi hæd kʌm. ʌpwɪn əz ʃi wɑz, ʃi kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hɪɹ ðə ɡɑɹdz meɪk ðɛɹ ɪkstʃeɪnʒ, bʌt ðeɪ maɪɾ əv hɝɾ əɹ ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðə ɹaɪt pleɪs. ɪf ðeɪ wɝ kʌmɪŋ tə si wʌt ðə nɔɪz hæd bɪn, ðə wɪnd wəd kip əɹ fɹəm hɪɹɪŋ əm əntɪl ðeɪ wɝ ɹaɪɾ ɑn tɑp ə hɝ. taɪm tə ɡoʊ. wɪð fɔɹ hɔɹsəz aʊɾ ə faɪv ɹʌnɪŋ lus, ðeɪ woʊn bi tʃeɪsɪŋ ɛniwʌn.

At the next picket-rope, though, and the next, and the next, the horses remained asleep, even when she cut her thumb and bit off a yelp. Sucking the cut, she looked warily back the way she had come. Upwind as she was, she could no longer hear the guards make their exchange, but they might have heard her if they were in the right place. If they were coming to see what the noise had been, the wind would keep her from hearing them until they were right on top of her. Time to go. With four horses out of five running loose, they won't be chasing anyone.

bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt muv. ʃi kəɾ ɪmædʒən lænz aɪz wən i hɝd wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn. ðəɹ wəd bi noʊ ækjəzeɪʃən ɪn ðɛm; hɝ ɹizənɪŋ wɑz saʊnd, ən i wəd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt ɛni mɔɹ ə hɝ. ʃi wɑz ə wɪzdəm, nɑɾ ə blʌɾi ɡɹeɪɾ ɪnvɪnsəbəl wɔɹɾɝ u kəd meɪk hɪmsɛlf ɔl bʌɾ ɪnvɪzəbəl. dʒɔ sɛt, ʃi muv tə ðə læs pɪkət-laɪn. ðə fɝs hɔɹs ɑn ɪt wɑz bɛlə.

But she did not move. She could imagine Lan's eyes when he heard what she had done. There would be no accusation in them; her reasoning was sound, and he would not expect any more of her. She was a Wisdom, not a bloody great invincible Warder who could make himself all but invisible. Jaw set, she moved to the last picket-line. The first horse on it was Bela.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɪsteɪkɪŋ ðət skwɑt, ʃæɡi ʃeɪp; fəɹ ðəɹ tə bi ənʌðɝ hɔɹs laɪk ðæt, hɪɹ ən naʊ, wɑz tu bɪɡ ə koʊɪnsɪɾəns. sʌɾənli ʃi wɑz soʊ ɡlæd ðət ʃi hæd nɑt lɛft ɔf ðɪs læs laɪn ðət ʃi wɑz ʃeɪkɪŋ. hɝ ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz tʃɹɛmbəl soʊ ðət ʃi wɑz əfɹeɪd tə tʌtʃ ðə pɪkət-ɹoʊp, bʌɾ əɹ maɪnd wɑz əz klɪɹ əz ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ wɔɾɝ. wɪtʃɛvɝ ə ðə bɔɪz wɑz ɪn ðə kæmp, ɛɡwin wɑz ðɛɹ, tu. ən ɪf ðeɪ lɛft ɹaɪɾɪŋ dʌbəl, səm ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən wəd kætʃ əm noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ wɛl ðə hɔɹsəz wɝ skæɾɝd, ən səm ə ðɛm wəd daɪ. ʃi wɑz əz sɝɾən əz ɪf ʃi wɝ lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə wɪnd. ðət stʌk ə spaɪk ə fɪɹ ɪndə hɝ bɛli, fɪɹ ə haʊ ʃi wɑz sɝɾən. ðɪs hæd nʌθɪŋ tə də wɪð wɛðɝ əɹ kɹɑps əɹ sɪknəs. waɪ dɪd mɔɪɹeɪn tɛl mi aɪ kən juz ðə paʊɝ? waɪ kʊdnt ʃi liv mi əloʊn?

There was no mistaking that squat, shaggy shape; for there to be another horse like that, here and now, was too big a coincidence. Suddenly she was so glad that she had not left off this last line that she was shaking. Her arms and legs trembled so that she was afraid to touch the picket-rope, but her mind was as clear as the Winespring Water. Whichever of the boys was in the camp, Egwene was there, too. And if they left riding double, some of the Children would catch them no matter how well the horses were scattered, and some of them would die. She was as certain as if she were listening to the wind. That stuck a spike of fear into her belly, fear of how she was certain. This had nothing to do with weather or crops or sickness. Why did Moiraine tell me I can use the Power? Why couldn't she leave me alone?

stʃɹeɪnʒli, ðə fɪɹ stɪld əɹ tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ. wɪð hænz əz stɛɾi əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ɡɹaɪndɪŋ ɝbz ɪn əɹ oʊn haʊs ʃi slɪt ðə pɪkət-ɹoʊp əz ʃi hæd ði ʌðɝz. θɹʌstɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ bæk ɪndə ɪts ʃiθ, ʃi əntaɪd bɛləz lɛd-ɹeɪn. ðə ʃæɡi mɛɹ woʊk wɪð ə stɑɹt, tɔsɪŋ əɹ hɛd, bʌt nɪneɪiv stʃɹoʊkt əɹ noʊz ən spoʊk kʌmfɝɾɪŋ wɝdz sɔfli ɪn əɹ ɪɹ. bɛlə ɡeɪv ə loʊ snɔɹɾ ən sim kɑntɛnt.

Strangely, the fear stilled her trembling. With hands as steady as if she were grinding herbs in her own house she slit the picket-rope as she had the others. Thrusting the dagger back into its sheath, she untied Bela's lead-rein. The shaggy mare woke with a start, tossing her head, but Nynaeve stroked her nose and spoke comforting words softly in her ear. Bela gave a low snort and seemed content.

ʌðɝ hɔɹsəz əlɔŋ ðət laɪn wɝ əweɪk, tu, ən lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ. ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ mændɑɹb, ʃi ɹitʃt hɛzɪɾəntli tə ðə nɛks lɛd-ɹeɪn, bʌt ðət hɔɹs ɡeɪv noʊ əbdʒɛkʃən tə ə stʃɹeɪnʒ hænd. ɪndid, ɪt sim tə wɑn səm ə ðə mʌzəl-stʃɹoʊkɪŋ ðət bɛlə hæd ɹəsivd. ʃi ɡɹɪp bɛləz ɹeɪn taɪtli ən ɹæp ði ʌðɝ ɝaʊn əɹ ʌðɝ ɹɪst, ɔl ðə waɪl wɑtʃɪŋ ðə kæmp nɝvəsli. ðə peɪl tɛns wɝ oʊnli θɝɾi jɑɹdz ɔf, ən ʃi kəd si mɛn muvɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛm. ɪf ðeɪ noʊɾəst ðə hɔɹsəz stɝɪŋ ən keɪm tə si wʌt kɑzd ɪt. . . .

Other horses along that line were awake, too, and looking at her. Remembering Mandarb, she reached hesitantly to the next lead-rein, but that horse gave no objection to a strange hand. Indeed, it seemed to want some of the muzzle-stroking that Bela had received. She gripped Bela's rein tightly and wrapped the other around her other wrist, all the while watching the camp nervously. The pale tents were only thirty yards off, and she could see men moving among them. If they noticed the horses stirring and came to see what caused it. . . .

dɛspɝətli ʃi wɪʃt fəɹ mɔɪɹeɪn nɑt tə weɪɾ ɑn əɹ ɹɪtɝn. wʌtɛvɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə du, lɛɾ əɹ də ɪt naʊ. laɪt, meɪk əɹ də ɪt naʊ, bɪfɔɹ. . . .

Desperately she wished for Moiraine not to wait on her return. Whatever the Aes Sedai was going to do, let her do it now. Light, make her do it now, before. . . .

əbɹʌpli laɪtnɪŋ ʃæɾɝd ðə naɪɾ oʊvɝhɛd, fəɹ ə moʊmən əbliɾɝeɪtɪŋ dɑɹknəs. θʌndɝ smoʊɾ əɹ ɪɹz, soʊ hɑɹd ʃi θɔɾ əɹ niz wəd bʌkəl, əz ə dʒæɡd tʃɹaɪɾənt stæb ðə ɡɹaʊn dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə hɔɹsəz, splæʃɪŋ dɝɾ ən ɹɑks laɪk ə faʊntən. ðə kɹæʃ ə ɹɪvən ɝθ fɔt ðə θʌndɝstʃɹoʊk. ðə hɔɹsəz wɛn mæd, skɹimɪŋ ən ɹɪɹɪŋ; ðə pɪkət-ɹoʊps snæp laɪk θɹɛd wɛɹ ʃi hæd kʌt ðɛm. ənʌðɝ laɪtnɪŋ boʊl slaɪs daʊn bɪfɔɹ ði ɪmədʒ ə ðə fɝs feɪɾəd.

Abruptly lightning shattered the night overhead, for a moment obliterating darkness. Thunder smote her ears, so hard she thought her knees would buckle, as a jagged trident stabbed the ground just beyond the horses, splashing dirt and rocks like a fountain. The crash of riven earth fought the thunderstroke. The horses went mad, screaming and rearing; the picket-ropes snapped like thread where she had cut them. Another lightning bolt sliced down before the image of the first faded.

nɪneɪiv wɑz tu bɪzi tə ɪɡzʌlt. ət ðə fɝs klæʃ bɛlə dʒɝkt wʌn weɪ waɪl ði ʌðɝ hɔɹs ɹɪɹɾ əweɪ ɪn ði ɑpəzət dɝɛkʃən. ʃi θɔɾ əɹ ɑɹmz wɝ biɪŋ pʊld aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ sɑkəts. fəɹ ən ɛnləs mɪnət ʃi hʌŋ səspɛndəd bɪtwin ðə hɔɹsəz, hɝ fiɾ ɔf ðə ɡɹaʊnd, hɝ skɹim flæɾənd baɪ ðə sɛkən kɹæʃ. əɡɛn ðə laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹʌk, ən əɡɛn, ən əɡɛn, ɪn wʌn kəntɪnjuəs, ɹeɪdʒɪŋ ɹɔɹ fɹəm ðə hɛvənz. bɔkt ɪn ðə weɪ ðeɪ wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ, ðə hɔɹsəz sɝdʒ bæk, lɛɾɪŋ əɹ dʒɹɑp. ʃi wɑntəd tə kɹaʊtʃ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ən suð əɹ tɔɹtʃɝd ʃoʊldɝz, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm. bɛlə ən ði ʌðɝ hɔɹs bəfeɪd hɝ, aɪz ɹoʊlɪŋ waɪldli tɪl oʊnli waɪts ʃoʊd, θɹɛɾənɪŋ tə nɑk əɹ daʊn ən tʃɹæmpəl hɝ. sʌmhaʊ ʃi meɪɾ əɹ ɑɹmz lɪft, klʌtʃt əɹ hænz ɪn bɛləz meɪn, pʊl hɝsɛlf ɑntu ðə hivɪŋ mɛɹz bæk. ði ʌðɝ ɹeɪn wɑz stɪl ɝaʊn əɹ ɹɪst, pʊl taɪɾ ɪndə ðə flɛʃ.

Nynaeve was too busy to exult. At the first clash Bela jerked one way while the other horse reared away in the opposite direction. She thought her arms were being pulled out of their sockets. For an endless minute she hung suspended between the horses, her feet off the ground, her scream flattened by the second crash. Again the lightning struck, and again, and again, in one continuous, raging roar from the heavens. Balked in the way they wanted to go, the horses surged back, letting her drop. She wanted to crouch on the ground and soothe her tortured shoulders, but there was no time. Bela and the other horse buffeted her, eyes rolling wildly till only whites showed, threatening to knock her down and trample her. Somehow she made her arms lift, clutched her hands in Bela's mane, pulled herself onto the heaving mare's back. The other rein was still around her wrist, pulled tight into the flesh.

hɝ dʒɔ dʒɹɑpt əz ə lɔŋ, ɡɹeɪ ʃædoʊ snɑɹəl pæst, simɪŋ tə ɪɡnɔɹ əɹ ən ðə hɔɹsəz wɪð hɝ, bʌt tiθ snæpɪŋ ət ðə kɹeɪzd ænəməlz naʊ dɑɹɾɪŋ ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən. ə sɛkənd ʃædoʊ ʌv dɛθ fɑloʊd kloʊs bɪhaɪnd. nɪneɪiv wɑntəd tə skɹim əɡɛn, bʌt nʌθɪŋ keɪm aʊt. wʊlvz! laɪt hɛlp ʌs! wʌɾ ɪz mɔɪɹeɪn duɪŋ?

Her jaw dropped as a long, gray shadow snarled past, seeming to ignore her and the horses with her, but teeth snapping at the crazed animals now darting in every direction. A second shadow of death followed close behind. Nynaeve wanted to scream again, but nothing came out. Wolves! Light help us! What is Moiraine doing?

ðə hilz ʃi dʌɡ ɪndə bɛləz saɪdz wɝ nɑt niɾəd. ðə mɛɹ ɹæn, ən ði ʌðɝ wɑz mɔɹ ðən hæpi tə fɑloʊ. ɛniwɛɹ, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ kəd ɹʌn, soʊ lɔŋ əz ðeɪ kəɾ ɪskeɪp ðə faɪɝ fɹəm ðə skaɪ ðət kɪl ðə naɪt.

The heels she dug into Bela's sides were not needed. The mare ran, and the other was more than happy to follow. Anywhere, so long as they could run, so long as they could escape the fire from the sky that killed the night.


tʃæptɝ θɝɾieɪt


CHAPTER 38

ɹɛskju


Rescue

pɛɹɪn ʃɪftəɾ əz bɛst i kəd wɪð ɪz ɹɪsts baʊn bɪhaɪn ɪm ən faɪnəli ɡeɪv ʌp wɪð ə saɪ. ɛvɹi ɹɑk i əvɔɪɾəd bɹɔɾ ɪm tu mɔɹ. ɔkwɝdli hi tʃɹaɪd tə wɝk ɪz kloʊk bæk oʊvɝ hɪm. ðə naɪt wɑz koʊld, ən ðə ɡɹaʊn sim tə dʒɹɔ ɔl ðə hiɾ aʊɾ ə hɪm, əz ɪt hæɾ ɛvɹi naɪt sɪns ðə waɪtkloʊks tʊk ðɛm. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən dɪd nɑt θɪŋk pɹɪznɝz niɾəd blæŋkəts, əɹ ʃɛltɝ. ɪspɛʃli nɑt deɪnʒɝəs dɑɹkfɹɛnz.

Perrin shifted as best he could with his wrists bound behind him and finally gave up with a sigh. Every rock he avoided brought him two more. Awkwardly he tried to work his cloak back over him. The night was cold, and the ground seemed to draw all the heat out of him, as it had every night since the Whitecloaks took them. The Children did not think prisoners needed blankets, or shelter. Especially not dangerous Darkfriends.

ɛɡwin leɪ hʌɾəld əɡɛnst ɪz bæk fəɹ wɔɹmθ, slipɪŋ ðə dip slip ʌv ɪɡzɔstʃən. ʃi nɛvɝ ivən mɝmɝɾ əɾ ɪz ʃɪftɪŋ. ðə sʌn wɑz lɔŋ aʊɝz bɪloʊ ðə hɝaɪzən, ən i ætʃt fɹəm hɛd tə fʊɾ æftɝ ə deɪ wɔkɪŋ bɪhaɪn ə hɔɹs wɪð ə hɔltɝ ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk, bʌt slip wəd nɑt kʌm fəɹ hɪm.

Egwene lay huddled against his back for warmth, sleeping the deep sleep of exhaustion. She never even murmured at his shifting. The sun was long hours below the horizon, and he ached from head to foot after a day walking behind a horse with a halter around his neck, but sleep would not come for him.

ðə kɑləm dɪd nɑt muv ðət fæst. wɪð moʊst ə ðɛɹ ɹimaʊns lɔs tə ðə wʊlvz ɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ, ðə waɪtkloʊks kəd nɑt pʊʃ ɑn əz hɑɹɾ əz ðeɪ wɑntəd; ðə dɪleɪ wɑz ənʌðɝ θɪŋ ðeɪ hɛld əɡɛns ði ɛmənz fildɝz. ðə sɪnwəs dʌbəl laɪn dɪd muv stɛɾəli, ðoʊ - lɔɹd bɔɹnhəl mɛn tə ɹitʃ keɪɛmlɪn ɪn taɪm fəɹ wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz - ən ɔlweɪz ɪn ðə bæk ə pɛɹɪnz maɪnd wɑz ðə fɪɹ ðəɾ ɪf i fɛl ðə waɪtkloʊk hoʊldɪŋ ɪz liʃ wəd nɑt stɑp, noʊ mæɾɝ lɔɹd kæptən bɔɹnhəlz ɔɹɾɝz tə kip əm əlaɪv fəɹ ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɪn æmədɔɹ. hi nu hi kəd nɑt seɪv hɪmsɛlf ɪf ðət hæpənd; ði oʊnli taɪmz ðeɪ fɹiɾ ɪz hænz wɝ wən i wɑz fɛɾ ən fəɹ vɪzəts tə ðə lætʃɹin pɪt. ðə hɔltɝ meɪɾ ɛvɹi stɛp moʊmɛntəs, ɛvɹi ɹɑk ʌndɝfʊt pətɛnʃəli feɪɾəl. hi wɔkt wɪð mʌsəlz tɛns, skænɪŋ ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪð æŋkʃəs aɪz. wɛnɛvɝ i ɡlænst əɾ ɛɡwin, ʃi wɑz duɪŋ ðə seɪm. wən ʃi mɛɾ ɪz aɪz, hɝ feɪs wɑz taɪɾ ən fɹaɪɾənd. niðɝ ə ðɛm dɛɹd teɪk ðɛɹ aɪz ɔf ðə ɡɹaʊn lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ə ɡlæns.

The column did not move that fast. With most of their remounts lost to the wolves in the stedding, the Whitecloaks could not push on as hard as they wanted; the delay was another thing they held against the Emond's Fielders. The sinuous double line did move steadily, though - Lord Bornhald meant to reach Caemlyn in time for Whatever it was - and always in the back of Perrin's mind was the fear that if he fell the Whitecloak holding his leash would not stop, no matter Lord Captain Bornhald's orders to keep them alive for the Questioners in Amador. He knew he could not save himself if that happened; the only times they freed his hands were when he was fed and for visits to the latrine pit. The halter made every step momentous, every rock underfoot potentially fatal. He walked with muscles tense, scanning the ground with anxious eyes. Whenever he glanced at Egwene, she was doing the same. When she met his eyes, her face was tight and frightened. Neither of them dared take their eyes off the ground long enough for more than a glance.

juʒəwəli hi kəlæps laɪk ə ɹʌŋ-aʊt ɹæɡ əz sun əz ðə waɪtkloʊks lɛɾ ɪm stɑp, bʌt tənaɪɾ ɪz maɪnd wɑz ɹeɪsɪŋ. hɪz skɪn kɹɔld wɪð dʒɹɛd ðət hæd bɪn bɪldɪŋ fəɹ deɪz. ɪf i kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, hi wəd si oʊnli ðə θɪŋz baɪɑɝ pɹɑməs fəɹ əm wʌns ðeɪ ɹitʃt æmədɔɹ.
