əbɹʌpli hi wɑz swɛpt ɝaʊn ə bɛnd, ən ðəɹ wɑz ðə pæləs. ðə stʃɹits, ivən fɑloʊɪŋ ðə nætʃɹəl kɑntʊɹz ə ðə lænd, hæd bɪn leɪɾ aʊt tə spaɪɹəl ɪn ɑn ðɪs - ðɪs ɡlimənz teɪl ə peɪl spaɪɹz ən ɡoʊldən doʊmz ən ɪntʃɹəkət stoʊnwɝk tʃɹeɪsɝiz, wɪð ðə bænɝ ʌv ændɝ weɪvɪŋ fɹəm ɛvɹi pɹɑmənəns, ə sɛntɝpis fəɹ wɪtʃ ɔl ði ʌðɝ vɪstəz hæd bɪn dɪzaɪnd. ɪt simd mɔɹ skʌlptɪd baɪ ən ɑɹɾəst ðən sɪmpli bɪlt laɪk ɔɹɾənɛɹi bɪldɪŋz.

Abruptly he was swept around a bend, and there was the Palace. The streets, even following the natural contours of the land, had been laid out to spiral in on this - this gleeman's tale of pale spires and golden domes and intricate stonework traceries, with the banner of Andor waving from every prominence, a centerpiece for which all the other vistas had been designed. It seemed more sculpted by an artist than simply built like ordinary buildings.

ðət ɡlɪmps ʃoʊɾ ɪm i wəd ɡɛt noʊ nɪɹɝ. noʊ wʌn wɑz biɪŋ əlaʊd kloʊs tə ðə pæləs. kwinz ɡɑɹdz meɪd skɑɹlət ɹæŋks tɛn dip flæŋkɪŋ ðə pæləs ɡeɪts. əlɔŋ ðə tɑps ə ðə waɪt wɔlz, ɑn haɪ bælkəniz ən taʊɝz, mɔɹ ɡɑɹdz stʊd ɹɪdʒɪdli stʃɹeɪt, baʊz pɹɪsaɪsli slæntəɾ əkɹɔs bɹɛstpleɪɾɪd tʃɛsts. ðeɪ, tu, lʊk laɪk sʌmθɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə ɡlimənz teɪl, ə ɡɑɹɾ ʌv ɑnɝ, bʌt ɹænd dɪd nɑt bɪliv ðət wɑz waɪ ðeɪ wɝ ðɛɹ. ðə klæmɝɪŋ kɹaʊd laɪnɪŋ ðə stʃɹits wɑz ɔlmoʊst sɑləd wɪð waɪt-ɹæp sɔɹdz, waɪɾ ɑɹmbænz, ən waɪt kɑkeɪdz. oʊnli hɪɹ ən ðəɹ wɑz ðə waɪt wɔl bɹoʊkən baɪ ə nɑɾ ə ɹɛd. ðə ɹɛd-junəfɔɹmd ɡɑɹdz simd ə θɪn bæɹiɝ əɡɛnst ɔl ðət waɪt.

That glimpse showed him he would get no nearer. No one was being allowed close to the Palace. Queen's Guards made scarlet ranks ten deep flanking the Palace gates. Along the tops of the white walls, on high balconies and towers, more Guards stood rigidly straight, bows precisely slanted across breastplated chests. They, too, looked like something out of a gleeman's tale, a guard of honor, but Rand did not believe that was why they were there. The clamoring crowd lining the streets was almost solid with white-wrapped swords, white armbands, and white cockades. Only here and there was the white wall broken by a knot of red. The red-uniformed guards seemed a thin barrier against all that white.

ɡɪvɪŋ ʌp ɑn meɪkɪŋ ɪz weɪ kloʊsɝ tə ðə pæləs, hi sɔɾ ə pleɪs wɛɹ i kəd juz ɪz haɪt tə ædvæntɪdʒ. hi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə bi ɪn ðə fɹʌn ɹoʊ tə si ɛvɹiθɪŋ. ðə kɹaʊd ʃɪftəd kɑnstənli, pipəl ʃʌvɪŋ tə ɡɛt nɪɹɝ ðə fɹʌnt, pipəl hɝiɪŋ ɔf tə wʌt ðeɪ θɔt wɑz ə bɛɾɝ væntədʒ pɔɪnt. ɪn wʌn ə ðoʊz ʃɪfs i faʊn hɪmsɛlf oʊnli θɹi pipəl fɹəm ði oʊpən stʃɹit, ən ɔl ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm wɝ ʃɔɹɾɝ ðən hi, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə pɪkmɛn. ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz. pipəl kɹaʊɾəd əɡɛnst ɪm fɹəm boʊθ saɪdz, swɛɾɪŋ fɹəm ðə pɹɛs ə soʊ mɛni bɑɾiz. ðoʊz bɪhaɪn ɪm mʌɾɝd əbaʊt nɑt biɪŋ eɪbəl tə si, ən tʃɹaɪd tə ɹɪɡəl pæst. hi stʊɾ ɪz ɡɹaʊnd, meɪkɪŋ ən ɪmpɝviəs wɔl wɪð ðoʊz tə iðɝ saɪd. hi wɑz kɑntɛnt. wən ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən pæs baɪ, hi wəd bi kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si ðə mænz feɪs klɪɹli.

Giving up on making his way closer to the Palace, he sought a place where he could use his height to advantage. He did not have to be in the front row to see everything. The crowd shifted constantly, people shoving to get nearer the front, people hurrying off to what they thought was a better vantage point. In one of those shifts he found himself only three people from the open street, and all in front of him were shorter than he, including the pikemen. Almost everyone was. People crowded against him from both sides, sweating from the press of so many bodies. Those behind him muttered about not being able to see, and tried to wriggle past. He stood his ground, making an impervious wall with those to either side. He was content. When the false Dragon passed by, he would be close enough to see the man's face clearly.

əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹiɾ ən daʊn təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪts tə ðə nu sɪɾi, ə ɹɪpəl pæs θɹu ðə taɪt-pækt kɹaʊd; ɝaʊn ðə kɝv, ən ɛɾi ʌv pipəl wɑz dʒɹɔɪŋ bæk tə lɛt sʌmθɪŋ ɡoʊ baɪ. ɪt wɑz nɑt laɪk ðə klɪɹ speɪs ðət fɑloʊd waɪtkloʊks ɑn ɛni deɪ bʌt tədeɪ. ðiz pipəl dʒɝk ðɛmsɛlvz bæk wɪð stɑɹɾəld ɡlænsɪz ðət bɪkeɪm ɡɹɪməsɪz ə dɪsteɪst. pɹɛsɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ, ðeɪ tɝn ðɛɹ feɪsəz fɹəm wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz, bʌt wɑtʃt aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝz ə ðɛɹ aɪz əntɪl ɪt wɑz pæst.

Across the street and down toward the gates to the New City, a ripple passed through the tight-packed crowd; around the curve, an eddy of people was drawing back to let something go by. It was not like the clear space that followed Whitecloaks on any day but today. These people jerked themselves back with startled glances that became grimaces of distaste. Pressing themselves out of the way, they turned their faces from Whatever it was, but watched out of the corners of their eyes until it was past.

ʌðɝ aɪz ɝaʊn ɪm noʊɾəd ðə dɪstɝbəns, tu. kid fəɹ ðə kʌmɪŋ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən bʌt wɪð nʌθɪŋ tə də naʊ bʌt weɪt, ðə kɹaʊd faʊn ɛniθɪŋ əɾ ɔl wɝði ʌv kɑmɛnt. hi hɝd spɛkjəleɪʃən ɹeɪnʒɪŋ fɹəm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ tə lɑɡən hɪmsɛlf, ən ə fju kɔɹsɝ sədʒɛstʃənz ðət bɹɔt ɹʌf læftɝ fɹəm ðə mɛn ən dɪsdeɪnfəl snɪfs fɹəm ðə wɪmən.

Other eyes around him noted the disturbance, too. Keyed for the coming of the Dragon but with nothing to do now but wait, the crowd found anything at all worthy of comment. He heard speculation ranging from an Aes Sedai to Logain himself, and a few coarser suggestions that brought rough laughter from the men and disdainful sniffs from the women.

ðə ɹɪpəl miændɝd θɹu ðə kɹaʊd, dʒɹɔɪŋ kloʊsɝ tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə stʃɹiɾ əz ɪt keɪm. noʊ wʌn sim tə hɛzəteɪɾ ɪn lɛɾɪŋ ɪt ɡoʊ wɛɹ ɪt wɑntəd, ivən ɪf ðət mɛn luzɪŋ ə ɡʊd spɑt fəɹ vjuɪŋ əz ðə kɹaʊd floʊd bæk ɪn ɑn ɪtsɛlf bɪhaɪn ðə pæsɪŋ. faɪnəli, dɝɛkli əkɹɔs fɹəm ɹænd, ðə kɹaʊd bʌlʒd ɪndə ðə stʃɹit, pʊʃɪŋ əsaɪd ɹɛd-kloʊk pɪkmɛn u stʃɹʌɡəl tə ʃʌv əm bæk, ən bɹoʊk oʊpən. ðə stupt ʃeɪp ðət ʃʌfəl hɛzɪɾəntli aʊɾ ɪndə ði oʊpən lʊk mɔɹ laɪk ə paɪl ə fɪlθi ɹæɡz ðən ə mæn. ɹænd hɝd mɝmɝz ə dɪsɡʌst ɝaʊn hɪm.

The ripple meandered through the crowd, drawing closer to the edge of the street as it came. No one seemed to hesitate in letting it go where it wanted, even if that meant losing a good spot for viewing as the crowd flowed back in on itself behind the passing. Finally, directly across from Rand, the crowd bulged into the street, pushing aside red-cloaked pikemen who struggled to shove them back, and broke open. The stooped shape that shuffled hesitantly out into the open looked more like a pile of filthy rags than a man. Rand heard murmurs of disgust around him.

ðə ɹæɡəd mæn pɔzd ɑn ðə fɑɹ ɛdʒ ə ðə stʃɹit. hɪz kaʊl, tɔɹn ən stɪf wɪð dɝt, swʌŋ bæk ən fɔɹθ əz ɪf sɝtʃɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ, əɹ lɪsnɪŋ. əbɹʌpli hi ɡeɪv ə wɝdləs kɹaɪ ən flʌŋ aʊɾ ə dɝɾi klɔ ʌv ə hænd, pɔɪntɪŋ stʃɹeɪɾ ət ɹænd. ɪmiɾiətli hi bɪɡæn tə skʌɾəl əkɹɔs ðə stʃɹit laɪk ə bʌɡ.

The ragged man paused on the far edge of the street. His cowl, torn and stiff with dirt, swung back and forth as if searching for something, or listening. Abruptly he gave a wordless cry and flung out a dirty claw of a hand, pointing straight at Rand. Immediately he began to scuttle across the street like a bug.

ðə bɛɡɝ. wʌtɛvɝ ɪl tʃæns hæd lɛd ðə mæn tə faɪn ɪm laɪk ðɪs, ɹænd wɑz sʌɾənli ʃʊɹ ðæt, dɑɹkfɹɛn əɹ nɑt, hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə miɾ ɪm feɪs-tə-feɪs. hi kəd fil ðə bɛɡɝz aɪz, laɪk ɡɹisi wɔɾɝ ɑn ɪz skɪn. ɪspɛʃli hi dɪd nɑt wɑn ðə mæn kloʊs tə hɪm hɪɹ, sɝaʊndəd baɪ pipəl bælənst ɑn ðə bɹɪŋk ə vaɪələns. ðə seɪm vɔɪsəz ðət hæd læf bɪfɔɹ naʊ kɝst ɪm əz i pʊʃt ɪz weɪ bæk, əweɪ fɹəm ðə stʃɹit.

The beggar. Whatever ill chance had led the man to find him like this, Rand was suddenly sure that, Darkfriend or not, he did not want to meet him face-to-face. He could feel the beggar's eyes, like greasy water on his skin. Especially he did not want the man close to him here, surrounded by people balanced on the brink of violence. The same voices that had laughed before now cursed him as he pushed his way back, away from the street.

hi hɝid, noʊɪŋ ðə dɛnsli pæk mæs θɹu wɪtʃ i hæd tə ʃʌv ən ɹɪɡəl wəd ɡɪv weɪ bɪfɔɹ ðə fɪlθi mæn. stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə fɔɹs ə pæθ θɹu ðə kɹaʊd, hi stæɡɝɾ ən ɔlmoʊs fɛl wən i əbɹʌpli bɹoʊk fɹi. fleɪlɪŋ ɪz ɑɹmz tə kip ɪz bæləns i tɝn ðə stæɡɝ ɪndə ə ɹʌn. pipəl pɔɪntəɾ ət hɪm; hi wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn nɑt pɹɛsɪŋ ði ʌðɝ weɪ, ən ɹʌnɪŋ ət ðæt. ʃaʊts fɑloʊd hɪm. hɪz kloʊk flæp bɪhaɪn hɪm, ɪkspoʊzɪŋ ɪz ɹɛd-klæd sɔɹd. wən i ɹilaɪz ðæt, hi ɹæn fæstɝ. ə loʊn səpɔɹɾɝ ə ðə kwin, ɹʌnɪŋ, kəd wɛl spɑɹk ə waɪt-kɑkeɪɾɪd mɑb tə pɝsut, ivən tədeɪ. hi ɹæn, lɛɾɪŋ ɪz lɔŋ lɛɡz it peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz. nɑɾ əntɪl ðə ʃaʊts wɝ lɛft fɑɹ bɪhaɪn dɪɾ i əlaʊ hɪmsɛlf tə kəlæps əɡɛnst ə wɔl, pæntɪŋ.

He hurried, knowing the densely packed mass through which he had to shove and wriggle would give way before the filthy man. Struggling to force a path through the crowd, he staggered and almost fell when he abruptly broke free. Flailing his arms to keep his balance he turned the stagger into a run. People pointed at him; he was the only one not pressing the other way, and running at that. Shouts followed him. His cloak flapped behind him, exposing his red-clad sword. When he realized that, he ran faster. A lone supporter of the Queen, running, could well spark a white-cockaded mob to pursuit, even today. He ran, letting his long legs eat paving stones. Not until the shouts were left far behind did he allow himself to collapse against a wall, panting.

hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wɛɹ i wɑz, ɪksɛp ðəɾ i wɑz stɪl wɪðɪn ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi. hi kəd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ haʊ mɛni twɪsts ən tɝnz i hæd teɪkən əlɔŋ ðoʊz kɝvɪŋ stʃɹits. pɔɪz tə ɹʌn əɡɛn, hi lʊk bæk ðə weɪ hi hæd kʌm. oʊnli wʌn pɝsən muvd ɑn ðə stʃɹit, ə wʊmən wɔkɪŋ plɑtʃədli əlɔŋ wɪð əɹ ʃɑpɪŋ bæskət. ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə sɪɾi wɑz ɡæðɝd fəɹ ə ɡlɪmps ə ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. hi kæn əv fɑloʊd mi. aɪ mʌst əv lɛft ɪm bɪhaɪnd.

He did not know where he was, except that he was still within the Inner City. He could not remember how many twists and turns he had taken along those curving streets. Poised to run again, he looked back the way he had come. Only one person moved on the street, a woman walking placidly along with her shopping basket. Almost everyone in the city was gathered for a glimpse of the false Dragon. He can't have followed me. I must have left him behind.

ðə bɛɡɝ wəd nɑt ɡɪv ʌp; hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ʌv ɪt, ðoʊ hi kəd nɑt seɪ waɪ. ðət ɹæɡəd ʃeɪp wəd bi wɝkɪŋ ɪts weɪ θɹu ðə kɹaʊdz ət ðət vɛɹi mɪnət, sɝtʃɪŋ, ən ɪf ɹænd ɹɪtɝn tə si lɑɡən i ɹæn ðə ɹɪsk ʌv ə miɾɪŋ. fəɹ ə moʊmən i kənsɪɾɝd ɡoʊɪŋ bæk tə ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ, bʌɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ i wəd nɛvɝ ɡɛɾ ənʌðɝ tʃæns tə si ə kwin, ən i hoʊpt i wəd nɛvɝ əv ənʌðɝ tə si ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. ðəɹ sim tə bi sʌmθɪŋ kaʊɝdli ɪn lɛɾɪŋ ə bɛn bɛɡɝ, ivən ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, tʃeɪs ɪm ɪndə haɪɾɪŋ.

The beggar would not give up; he was sure of it, though he could not say why. That ragged shape would be working its way through the crowds at that very minute, searching, and if Rand returned to see Logain he ran the risk of a meeting. For a moment he considered going back to The Queen's Blessing, but he was sure he would never get another chance to see a Queen, and he hoped he would never have another to see a false Dragon. There seemed to be something cowardly in letting a bent beggar, even a Darkfriend, chase him into hiding.

hi lʊkt ɝaʊnd, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ. ðə weɪ ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi wɑz leɪɾ aʊt, bɪldɪŋz wɝ kɛp loʊ, ɪf ðəɹ wɝ bɪldɪŋz əɾ ɔl, soʊ ðət sʌmwʌn stændɪŋ əɾ ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ spɑt wəɾ əv nʌθɪŋ tə ɪntɝʌp ðə plæn vju. ðəɹ hæd tə bi pleɪsəz fɹəm wɛɹ i kəd si ðə pɹəsɛʃən pæs wɪð ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. ivən ɪf i kəd nɑt si ðə kwin, hi kəd si lɑɡən. sʌɾənli dɪtɝmənd, hi sɛɾ ɔf.

He looked around, considering. The way the Inner City was laid out, buildings were kept low, if there were buildings at all, so that someone standing at a particular spot would have nothing to interrupt the planned view. There had to be places from where he could see the procession pass with the false Dragon. Even if he could not see the Queen, he could see Logain. Suddenly determined, he set off.

ɪn ðə nɛkst aʊɝ i faʊn sɛvɹəl sətʃ pleɪsəz, ɛvɹi læst wʌn ɔlɹɛɾi pæk tʃik-tə-tʃik wɪð pipəl əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə kɹʌʃ əlɔŋ ðə pɹəsɛʃən ɹut. ðeɪ wɝ ə sɑləd fɹʌn ʌv waɪt kɑkeɪdz ən ɑɹmbænz. noʊ ɹɛɾ əɾ ɔl. θɪŋkɪŋ wʌt ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz sɔɹd maɪt də ɪn ə kɹaʊd laɪk ðæt, hi slɪpt əweɪ kɛɹfəli, ən kwɪkli.

In the next hour he found several such places, every last one already packed cheek-to-cheek with people avoiding the crush along the procession route. They were a solid front of white cockades and armbands. No red at all. Thinking what the sight of his sword might do in a crowd like that, he slipped away carefully, and quickly.

ʃaʊɾɪŋ floʊɾəd ʌp fɹəm ðə nu sɪɾi, kɹaɪz ən ðə blɛɹɪŋ ə tʃɹʌmpəts, ðə mɑɹʃəl biɾ ə dʒɹʌmz. lɑɡən ən ɪz ɛskɔɹt wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ tə ðə pæləs.

Shouting floated up from the New City, cries and the blaring of trumpets, the martial beat of drums. Logain and his escort were already in Caemlyn, already on their way to the Palace.

dɪspɪɹəɾɪd, hi wɑndɝd ði ɔl bʌɾ ɛmpti stʃɹits, stɪl hæfhɑɹɾɪdli hoʊpɪŋ tə faɪn səm weɪ tə si lɑɡən. hɪz aɪz fɛl ɑn ðə sloʊp, bɛɹ ə bɪldɪŋz, ɹaɪzɪŋ əbʌv ðə stʃɹit wɛɹ i wɑz wɔkɪŋ. ɪn ə nɔɹməl spɹɪŋ ðə sloʊp wəd bi ən ɪkspæns ə flaʊɝz ən ɡɹæs, bʌt naʊ ɪt wɑz bɹaʊn ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə haɪ wɔl əlɔŋ ɪts kɹɛst, ə wɔl oʊvɝ wɪtʃ ðə tɑps ə tʃɹiz wɝ vɪzəbəl.

Dispirited, he wandered the all but empty streets, still halfheartedly hoping to find some way to see Logain. His eyes fell on the slope, bare of buildings, rising above the street where he was walking. In a normal spring the slope would be an expanse of flowers and grass, but now it was brown all the way to the high wall along its crest, a wall over which the tops of trees were visible.

ðɪs pɑɹɾ ə ðə stʃɹit hæd nɑt bɪn dɪzaɪn fəɹ ɛni ɡɹæn vju, bʌt dʒʌst əhɛd, oʊvɝ ðə ɹuftɑps, hi kəd si səm ə ðə pæləs spaɪɹz, tɑp baɪ waɪt laɪən bænɝz flʌɾɝɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪɡzækli wɛɹ ðə kɝv ə ðə stʃɹit ɹæn æftɝ ɪt ɹaʊndəd ðə hɪl bɪɑn ɪz saɪt, bʌɾ i sʌɾənli hæɾ ə θɔɾ əbaʊt ðət hɪltɑp wɔl.

This part of the street had not been designed for any grand view, but just ahead, over the rooftops, he could see some of the Palace spires, topped by White Lion banners fluttering in the wind. He was not sure exactly where the curve of the street ran after it rounded the hill beyond his sight, but he suddenly had a thought about that hilltop wall.

ðə dʒɹʌmz ən tʃɹʌmpəts wɝ dʒɹɔɪŋ nɪɹɝ, ðə ʃaʊɾɪŋ ɡɹoʊɪŋ laʊɾɝ. æŋkʃəsli hi skɹæmbəld ʌp ðə sloʊp. ɪt wɑz nɑt mɛn tə bi klaɪmd, bʌɾ i dʌɡ hɪz buts ɪndə ðə dɛd sɑɾ ən pʊl hɪmsɛlf ʌp juzɪŋ lifləs ʃɹʌbz əz hændhoʊlz. pæntɪŋ əz mʌtʃ wɪð dɪzaɪɝ əz ɛfɝt, hi skɹæmbəl ðə læs jɑɹdz tə ðə wɔl. ɪt ɹɪɹɾ əbʌv hɪm, izəli twaɪs ɪz haɪɾ ən mɔɹ. ði ɛɹ θʌndɝd wɪð ðə dʒɹʌmbit, ɹæŋ wɪð tʃɹʌmpət blæsts.

The drums and trumpets were drawing nearer, the shouting growing louder. Anxiously he scrambled up the slope. It was not meant to be climbed, but he dug his boots into the dead sod and pulled himself up using leafless shrubs as handholds. Panting as much with desire as effort, he scrambled the last yards to the wall. It reared above him, easily twice his height and more. The air thundered with the drumbeat, rang with trumpet blasts.

ðə feɪs ə ðə wɔl hæd bɪn lɛf mʌtʃ ɪn ðə nætʃɹəl steɪɾ ə ðə stoʊn, ðə hjudʒ blɑks fɪɾəd təɡɛðɝ soʊ wɛl ðət ðə dʒɔɪnz wɝ nɪɹli ɪnvɪzəbəl, ðə ɹʌnəs meɪkɪŋ ɪt sim ɔlmoʊst ə nætʃɹəl klɪf. ɹænd ɡɹɪnd. ðə klɪfs dʒʌs bɪɑn ðə sæn hɪlz wɝ haɪɝ, ən ivən pɛɹɪn hæd klaɪm ðoʊz. hɪz hænz sɔt ɹɑki nɑbz, hɪz buɾɪd fit faʊn ɹɪdʒəz. ðə dʒɹʌmz ɹeɪst ɪm əz i klaɪmd. hi ɹəfjuz tə lɛɾ əm wɪn. hi wəd ɹitʃ ðə tɑp bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə pæləs. ɪn ɪz heɪst, ðə stoʊn tɔɹ ɪz hænz ən skɹeɪpt ɪz niz θɹu hɪz bɹitʃɪz, bʌɾ i flʌŋ ɪz ɑɹmz oʊvɝ ðə tɑp ən hiv hɪmsɛlf ʌp wɪð ə sɛns ə vɪktɝi.

The face of the wall had been left much in the natural state of the stone, the huge blocks fitted together so well that the joins were nearly invisible, the roughness making it seem almost a natural cliff. Rand grinned. The cliffs just beyond the Sand Hills were higher, and even Perrin had climbed those. His hands sought rocky knobs, his booted feet found ridges. The drums raced him as he climbed. He refused to let them win. He would reach the top before they reached the Palace. In his haste, the stone tore his hands and scraped his knees through his breeches, but he flung his arms over the top and heaved himself up with a sense of victory.

heɪstəli hi twɪstəd hɪmsɛlf ɝaʊn tə ə siɾ ɑn ðə flæt, nɛɹoʊ tɑp ə ðə wɔl. ðə lifi bɹæntʃəz ʌv ə taʊɝɪŋ tʃɹi stʌk aʊɾ oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd, bʌɾ i hæd noʊ θɔt fəɹ ðæt. hi lʊkt əkɹɔs taɪld ɹuftɑps, bʌt fɹəm ðə wɔl ɪz laɪn ə saɪt wɑz klɪɹ. hi lin aʊt, dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl, ən kəd si ðə pæləs ɡeɪt, ən ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz dʒɹɔn ʌp ðɛɹ, ən ði ɪkspɛktən kɹaʊd. ɪkspɛktənt. ðɛɹ ʃaʊts dʒɹaʊn aʊt baɪ ðə θʌndɝ ə dʒɹʌmz ən tʃɹʌmpəts, bʌt weɪɾɪŋ stɪl. hi ɡɹɪnd. aɪ wʌn.

Hastily he twisted himself around to a seat on the flat, narrow top of the wall. The leafy branches of a towering tree stuck out over his head, but he had no thought for that. He looked across tiled rooftops, but from the wall his line of sight was clear. He leaned out, just a little, and could see the Palace gate, and the Queen's Guards drawn up there, and the expectant crowd. Expectant. Their shouts drowned out by the thunder of drums and trumpets, but waiting still. He grinned. I won.

ivən əz i sɛɾəld ɪn pleɪs, ðə fɝs pɑɹɾ ə ðə pɹəsɛʃən ɹaʊndəd ðə faɪnəl kɝv bɪfɔɹ ðə pæləs. twɛnti ɹæŋks ə tʃɹʌmpəɾɝz keɪm fɝst, splɪɾɪŋ ði ɛɹ wɪð pil æftɝ tʃɹaɪʌmfən pil, ə fænfɛɹ ə vɪktɝi. bɪhaɪn ðɛm, əz mɛni dʒɹʌmɝz θʌndɝd. ðən keɪm ðə bænɝz ə keɪɛmlɪn, waɪt laɪənz ɑn ɹɛd, bɔɹn baɪ maʊntəd mɛn, fɑloʊd baɪ ðə soʊlʒɝz ə keɪɛmlɪn, ɹæŋk ɑn ɹæŋk ɑn ɹæŋk ə hɔɹsmən, ɑɹmɝ ɡlimɪŋ, lænsɪz pɹaʊdli hɛld, kɹɪmzən pɛnəns flʌɾɝɪŋ. tʃɹɛbəl ɹoʊz ə pɪkmɛn ən ɑɹtʃɝz flæŋk ðɛm, ən keɪm ɑn ən ɑn æftɝ ðə hɔɹsmən bɪɡæn pæsɪŋ bɪtwin ðə weɪɾɪŋ ɡɑɹdz ən θɹu ðə pæləs ɡeɪts.

Even as he settled in place, the first part of the procession rounded the final curve before the Palace. Twenty ranks of trumpeters came first, splitting the air with peal after triumphant peal, a fanfare of victory. Behind them, as many drummers thundered. Then came the banners of Caemlyn, white lions on red, borne by mounted men, followed by the soldiers of Caemlyn, rank on rank on rank of horsemen, armor gleaming, lances proudly held, crimson pennants fluttering. Treble rows of pikemen and archers flanked them, and came on and on after the horsemen began passing between the waiting Guards and through the Palace gates.

ðə læst ə ðə fʊt soʊlʒɝz ɹaʊndəd ðə kɝv, ən bɪhaɪn əm wɑz ə mæsɪv wæɡən. sɪkstin hɔɹsəz pʊld ɪɾ ɪn hɪtʃɪz ə fɔɹ. ɪn ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ɪts flæt bɛd wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ keɪdʒ ʌv aɪɝn bɑɹz, ən ɑn itʃ kɔɹnɝ ə ðə wæɡoʊnb sæt tu wɪmən, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə keɪdʒ əz ɪntɛnli əz ɪf ðə pɹəsɛʃən ən ðə kɹaʊd dɪd nɑɾ ɪɡzɪst. ɛɛs sədaɪ, hi wɑz sɝɾən. bɪtwin ðə wæɡən ən ðə fʊtmən, ən tə iðɝ saɪd, ɹoʊɾ ə dʌzən wɔɹɾɝz, ðɛɹ kloʊks swɝlɪŋ ən tæŋəlɪŋ ði aɪ. ɪf ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪɡnɔɹd ðə kɹaʊd, ðə wɔɹɾɝz skæn ɪɾ əz ɪf ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ʌðɝ ɡɑɹdz bʌt ðeɪ.

The last of the foot soldiers rounded the curve, and behind them was a massive wagon. Sixteen horses pulled it in hitches of four. In the center of its flat bed was a large cage of iron bars, and on each corner of the wagonbed sat two women, watching the cage as intently as if the procession and the crowd did not exist. Aes Sedai, he was certain. Between the wagon and the footmen, and to either side, rode a dozen Warders, their cloaks swirling and tangling the eye. If the Aes Sedai ignored the crowd, the Warders scanned it as if there were no other guards but they.

wɪð ɔl ə ðæt, ɪt wɑz ðə mæn ɪn ðə keɪdʒ u kɑɾ ən hɛld ɹændz aɪz. hi wɑz nɑt kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si lɑɡənz feɪs, əz i hæd wɑntəd tə, bʌt sʌɾənli hi θɔɾ i wɑz əz kloʊz əz i kɛɹd fɔɹ. ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən wɑz ə tɔl mæn, wɪð lɔŋ, dɑɹk hɛɹ kɝlɪŋ ɝaʊn ɪz bɹɔd ʃoʊldɝz. hi hɛl hɪmsɛlf əpɹaɪɾ əɡɛns ðə sweɪ ʌv ðə wæɡən wɪð wʌn hæn ɑn ðə bɑɹz oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. hɪz kloʊðz simd ɔɹɾənɛɹi, ə kloʊk ən koʊɾ ən bɹitʃɪz ðət wəd nɑɾ əv kɑz kɑmɛn ɪn ɛni fɑɹmɪŋ vɪlədʒ. bʌt ðə weɪ hi wɔɹ ðɛm. ðə weɪ hi hɛl hɪmsɛlf. lɑɡən wɑz ə kɪŋ ɪn ɛvɹi ɪntʃ ə hɪm. ðə keɪdʒ maɪɾ əz wɛl nɑɾ əv bɪn ðɛɹ. hi hɛl hɪmsɛlf ɪɹɛkt, hɛd haɪ, ən lʊkt oʊvɝ ðə kɹaʊɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd kʌm tə də hɪm ɑnɝ. ən wɛɹɛvɝ ɪz ɡeɪz swɛpt, ðəɹ ðə pipəl fɛl saɪlənt, stɛɹɪŋ bæk ɪn ɑ. wən lɑɡənz aɪz lɛf ðɛm, ðeɪ skɹimd wɪð ɹidʌbəl fjʊɹi əz ɪf tə meɪk ʌp fəɹ ðɛɹ saɪləns, bʌɾ ɪt meɪd noʊ dɪfɝəns ɪn ðə weɪ ðə mæn stʊd, əɹ ɪn ðə saɪləns ðət pæst əlɔŋ wɪð hɪm. əz ðə wæɡən ɹoʊl θɹu ðə pæləs ɡeɪts, hi tɝn tə lʊk bæk ət ði əsɛmbəl mæsəz. ðeɪ haʊld ət hɪm, bɪɑnd wɝdz, ə weɪv ə ʃɪɹ ænəməl heɪɾ ən fɪɹ, ən lɑɡən θɹu bæk ɪz hɛɾ ən læft əz ðə pæləs swɑloʊd hɪm.

With all of that, it was the man in the cage who caught and held Rand's eyes. He was not close enough to see Logain's face, as he had wanted to, but suddenly he thought he was as close as he cared for. The false Dragon was a tall man, with long, dark hair curling around his broad shoulders. He held himself upright against the sway of the wagon with one hand on the bars over his head. His clothes seemed ordinary, a cloak and coat and breeches that would not have caused comment in any farming village. But the way he wore them. The way he held himself. Logain was a king in every inch of him. The cage might as well not have been there. He held himself erect, head high, and looked over the crowd as if they had come to do him honor. And wherever his gaze swept, there the people fell silent, staring back in awe. When Logain's eyes left them, they screamed with redoubled fury as if to make up for their silence, but it made no difference in the way the man stood, or in the silence that passed along with him. As the wagon rolled through the Palace gates, he turned to look back at the assembled masses. They howled at him, beyond words, a wave of sheer animal hate and fear, and Logain threw back his head and laughed as the Palace swallowed him.

ʌðɝ kəntɪnʒənts fɑloʊd bɪhaɪn ðə wæɡənz, wɪð bænɝz ɹɛpɹɪzɛntɪŋ mɔɹ u hæd fɔɾ ən dɪfiɾəd ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. ðə ɡoʊldən biz ʌv ɪljən, ðə θɹi waɪt kɹɛsəns ə tɛɹ, ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn ə kɛɹhin, ʌðɝz, mɛni ʌðɝz, ʌv neɪʃənz ən ə sɪɾiz, ən ʌv ɡɹeɪt mɛn wɪð ðɛɹ oʊn tʃɹʌmpəts, ðɛɹ oʊn dʒɹʌmz tə θʌndɝ ðɛɹ ɡɹænduɹ. ɪt wɑz æntiklaɪmæktɪk æftɝ lɑɡən.

Other contingents followed behind the wagons, with banners representing more who had fought and defeated the false Dragon. The Golden Bees of Illian, the three White Crescents of Tear, the Rising Sun of Cairhien, others, many others, of nations and of cities, and of great men with their own trumpets, their own drums to thunder their grandeur. It was anticlimactic after Logain.

ɹænd lin aʊɾ ə bɪt fɝðɝ tə tʃɹaɪ tə kætʃ wʌn læst saɪɾ ə ðə keɪdʒ mæn. hi wɑz dɪfiɾəd, wɑzn hi? laɪt, hi wʊdn bi ɪn ə blʌɾi keɪdʒ ɪf i wɑzn dɪfiɾəd.

Rand leaned out a bit further to try to catch one last sight of the caged man. He was defeated, wasn't he? Light, he wouldn't be in a bloody cage if he wasn't defeated.

oʊvɝbælənst, hi slɪpt ən ɡɹæbd ət ðə tɑp ə ðə wɔl, pʊl hɪmsɛlf bæk tə ə sʌmwʌt seɪfɝ sit. wɪð lɑɡən ɡɔn, hi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə ðə bɝnɪŋ ɪn ɪz hænz, wɛɹ ðə stoʊn hæd skɹeɪpt ɪz pɑmz ən fɪŋɡɝz. jɛɾ i kəd nɑt ʃeɪk fɹi ʌv ði ɪmədʒəz. ðə keɪdʒ ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. lɑɡən, ʌndɪfiɾɪd. noʊ mæɾɝ ðə keɪdʒ, ðət hæd nɑt bɪn ə dɪfiɾəd mæn. hi ʃɪvɝɾ ən ɹʌbd ɪz stɪŋɪŋ hænz ɑn ɪz θaɪz.

Overbalanced, he slipped and grabbed at the top of the wall, pulled himself back to a somewhat safer seat. With Logain gone, he became aware of the burning in his hands, where the stone had scraped his palms and fingers. Yet he could not shake free of the images. The cage and the Aes Sedai. Logain, undefeated. No matter the cage, that had not been a defeated man. He shivered and rubbed his stinging hands on his thighs.

"waɪ wɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm?" hi wʌndɝɾ əlaʊd.

"Why were the Aes Sedai watching him?" he wondered aloud.

"ðeɪɹ kipɪŋ ɪm fɹəm tʌtʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, sɪli."

"They're keeping him from touching the True Source, silly."

hi dʒɝk tə lʊk ʌp, təwɔɹd ðə ɡɝlz vɔɪs, ən sʌɾənli hɪz pɹikɛɹiəs sit wɑz ɡɔn. hi hæɾ oʊnli taɪm tə ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz tɑpəlɪŋ bækwɝd, fɔlɪŋ, wən sʌmθɪŋ stʃɹʌk ɪz hɛɾ ən ə læfɪŋ lɑɡən tʃeɪst ɪm ɪndə spɪnɪŋ dɑɹknəs.

He jerked to look up, toward the girl's voice, and suddenly his precarious seat was gone. He had only time to realize that he was toppling backward, falling, when something struck his head and a laughing Logain chased him into spinning darkness.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾi

ðə wɛb taɪɾənz


The Web Tightens

ɪt sim tə ɹænd ðəɾ i wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ət teɪbəl wɪð lɑɡən ən mɔɪɹeɪn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən sæt wɑtʃɪŋ ɪm saɪlənli, əz ɪf niðɝ nu ði ʌðɝ wɑz ðɛɹ. əbɹʌpli hi ɹilaɪz ðə wɔlz ə ðə ɹum wɝ bɪkʌmɪŋ ɪndɪstɪŋkt, feɪɾɪŋ ɔf ɪndə ɡɹeɪ. ə sɛns ə ɝdʒənsi bɪlt ɪn hɪm. ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ, blɝɪŋ əweɪ. wən i lʊk bæk tə ðə teɪbəl, mɔɪɹeɪn ən lɑɡən hæd vænɪʃt, ən bælzəmən sæt ðəɹ ɪnstɛd. ɹændz hoʊl bɑɾi vaɪbɹeɪɾɪd wɪð ɝdʒənsi; ɪt hʌmd ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz hɛd, laʊɾɝ ən laʊɾɝ. ðə hʌm bɪkeɪm ðə paʊndɪŋ ə blʌɾ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz.

It seemed to Rand that he was sitting at table with Logain and Moiraine. The Aes Sedai and the false Dragon sat watching him silently, as if neither knew the other was there. Abruptly he realized the walls of the room were becoming indistinct, fading off into gray. A sense of urgency built in him. Everything was going, blurring away. When he looked back to the table, Moiraine and Logain had vanished, and Ba'alzamon sat there instead. Rand's whole body vibrated with urgency; it hummed inside his head, louder and louder. The hum became the pounding of blood in his ears.

wɪð ə dʒɝk i sæɾ ʌp, ən ɪmiɾiətli ɡɹoʊn ən klʌtʃt ɪz hɛd, sweɪɪŋ. hɪz hoʊl skʌl hɝt; hɪz lɛf hæn faʊn stɪki dæmpnəs ɪn ɪz hɛɹ. hi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ɑn ɡɹin ɡɹæs. ðət tʃɹʌbəl hɪm, veɪɡli, bʌɾ ɪz hɛd spʌn ən ɛvɹiθɪŋ i lʊkt ət lɝtʃt, ən ɔl i kəd θɪŋk ʌv wɑz laɪɪŋ daʊn əntɪl ɪt stɑpt.

With a jerk he sat up, and immediately groaned and clutched his head, swaying. His whole skull hurt; his left hand found sticky dampness in his hair. He was sitting on the ground, on green grass. That troubled him, vaguely, but his head spun and everything he looked at lurched, and all he could think of was lying down until it stopped.

ðə wɔl! ðə ɡɝlz vɔɪs!

The wall! The girl's voice!

stɛɾiɪŋ hɪmsɛlf wɪð wʌn hæn flæɾ ɑn ðə ɡɹæs, hi lʊkt ɝaʊn sloʊli. hi hæd tə də ɪt sloʊli; wən i tʃɹaɪd tə tɝn ɪz hɛd kwɪkli ɛvɹiθɪŋ stɑɹɾəd wɝlɪŋ əɡɛn. hi wɑz ɪn ə ɡɑɹɾən, əɹ ə pɑɹk; ə sleɪt-peɪvd wɔk miændɝd baɪ θɹu flaʊɝɪŋ bʊʃəz nɑt sɪks fiɾ əweɪ, wɪð ə waɪt stoʊn bɛntʃ bɪsaɪɾ ɪɾ ən ə lifi ɑɹbɝ oʊvɝ ðə bɛntʃ fəɹ ʃeɪd. hi hæd fɔlən ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔl. ən ðə ɡɝl?

Steadying himself with one hand flat on the grass, he looked around slowly. He had to do it slowly; when he tried to turn his head quickly everything started whirling again. He was in a garden, or a park; a slate-paved walk meandered by through flowering bushes not six feet away, with a white stone bench beside it and a leafy arbor over the bench for shade. He had fallen inside the wall. And the girl?

hi faʊn ðə tʃɹi, kloʊs bɪhaɪn ɪz bæk, ən faʊn hɝ, tu - klaɪmɪŋ daʊn aʊɾ ʌv ɪt. ʃi ɹitʃt ðə ɡɹaʊn ən tɝn tə feɪs hɪm, ən i blɪŋkt ən ɡɹoʊn əɡɛn. ə dip blu vɛlvət kloʊk laɪnd wɪð peɪl fɝ ɹɛstəɾ ɑn əɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ɪts hʊd hæŋɪŋ daʊn bɪhaɪn tə hɝ weɪst wɪð ə klʌstɝ ə sɪlvɝ bɛlz ət ðə pik. ðeɪ dʒɪŋɡəld wən ʃi muvd. ə sɪlvɝ fɪləɡɹi sɝklət hɛld əɹ lɔŋ, ɹɛd-ɡoʊl kɝlz, ən dɛləkət sɪlvɝ ɹɪŋz hʌŋ əɾ əɹ ɪɹz, waɪl ə nɛkləs ə hɛvi sɪlvɝ lɪŋks ən dɑɹk ɡɹin stoʊnz i θɔt wɝ ɛmɹəlz leɪ ɝaʊn əɹ θɹoʊt. hɝ peɪl blu dʒɹɛs wɑz smʌdʒd wɪð bɑɹk steɪnz fɹəm əɹ tʃɹi klaɪmɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz stɪl sɪlk, ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd wɪð peɪnsteɪkɪŋli ɪntʃɹəkət dɪzaɪnz, ðə skɝt slæʃt wɪð ɪnsɝts ðə kʌlɝ ə ɹɪtʃ kɹim. ə waɪd bɛlt ʌv woʊvən sɪlvɝ ɪnsɝkəld əɹ weɪst, ən vɛlvət slɪpɝz pik fɹəm ʌndɝ ðə hɛm ə hɝ dʒɹɛs.

He found the tree, close behind his back, and found her, too - climbing down out of it. She reached the ground and turned to face him, and he blinked and groaned again. A deep blue velvet cloak lined with pale fur rested on her shoulders, its hood hanging down behind to her waist with a cluster of silver bells at the peak. They jingled when she moved. A silver filigree circlet held her long, red-gold curls, and delicate silver rings hung at her ears, while a necklace of heavy silver links and dark green stones he thought were emeralds lay around her throat. Her pale blue dress was smudged with bark stains from her tree climbing, but it was still silk, and embroidered with painstakingly intricate designs, the skirt slashed with inserts the color of rich cream. A wide belt of woven silver encircled her waist, and velvet slippers peeked from under the hem of her dress.

hi hæɾ oʊnli ɛvɝ sin tu wɪmən dʒɹɛst ɪn ðɪs fæʃən, mɔɪɹeɪn ən ðə dɑɹkfɹɛn u hæd tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl mæt ən hɪm. hi kəd nɑt bɪɡɪn tə ɪmædʒən u wəd tʃuz tə klaɪm tʃɹiz ɪn kloʊðz laɪk ðæt, bʌɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ ʃi hæd tə bi sʌmwʌn ɪmpɔɹɾənt. ðə weɪ ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɪm ɹidʌbəl ði ɪmpɹɛʃən. ʃi dɪd nɑt sim ɪn ðə lis tʃɹʌbəld ət hævɪŋ ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ tʌmbəl ɪndə hɝ ɡɑɹɾən. ðəɹ wɑz ə sɛlf-pəzɛʃən əbaʊɾ əɹ ðət meɪɾ ɪm θɪŋk ə nɪneɪiv, əɹ mɔɪɹeɪn.

He had only ever seen two women dressed in this fashion, Moiraine and the Darkfriend who had tried to kill Mat and him. He could not begin to imagine who would choose to climb trees in clothes like that, but he was sure she had to be someone important. The way she was looking at him redoubled the impression. She did not seem in the least troubled at having a stranger tumble into her garden. There was a self-possession about her that made him think of Nynaeve, or Moiraine.

hi wɑz soʊ ɛnmɛʃt ɪn wɝiɪŋ wɛðɝ əɹ nɑɾ i hæd ɡɑɾən hɪmsɛlf ɪndə tʃɹʌbəl, wɛðɝ əɹ nɑt ʃi wɑz sʌmwʌn u kəɾ ən wəd kɔl ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz ivən ɑn ə deɪ wən ðeɪ hæɾ ʌðɝ θɪŋz tə ɑkjəpaɪ ðɛm, ðəɾ ɪt tʊk ɪm ə fju moʊməns tə si pæs ði ɪlæbɹət kloʊðz ən lɔfti æɾətud tə ðə ɡɝl hɝsɛlf. ʃi wɑz pɝhæps tu əɹ θɹi jɪɹz jʌŋɡɝ ðən hi, tɔl fəɹ ə ɡɝl, ən bjuɾəfəl, hɝ feɪs ə pɝfəkt oʊvəl fɹeɪm baɪ ðət mæs ə sʌnbɝs kɝlz, hɝ lɪps fʊl ən ɹɛd, hɝ aɪz blɝ ðən i kəd bɪliv. ʃi wɑz kəmplitli dɪfɹən fɹəm ɛɡwin ɪn haɪɾ ən feɪs ən bɑɾi, bʌɾ ɛvɹi bɪɾ əz bjuɾəfəl. hi fɛlt ə twɪnʒ ʌv ɡɪlt, bʌt toʊl hɪmsɛlf ðət dɪnaɪɪŋ wʌɾ ɪz aɪz sɔ wəd nɑt bɹɪŋ ɛɡwin seɪfli tə keɪɛmlɪn wʌn wɪt fæstɝ.

He was so enmeshed in worrying whether or not he had gotten himself into trouble, whether or not she was someone who could and would call the Queen's Guards even on a day when they had other things to occupy them, that it took him a few moments to see past the elaborate clothes and lofty attitude to the girl herself. She was perhaps two or three years younger than he, tall for a girl, and beautiful, her face a perfect oval framed by that mass of sunburst curls, her lips full and red, her eyes bluer than he could believe. She was completely different from Egwene in height and face and body, but every bit as beautiful. He felt a twinge of guilt, but told himself that denying what his eyes saw would not bring Egwene safely to Caemlyn one whit faster.

ə skɹæbəlɪŋ saʊn keɪm fɹəm ʌp ɪn ðə tʃɹi ən bɪts ə bɑɹk fɛl, fɑloʊd baɪ ə bɔɪ dʒɹɑpɪŋ laɪtli tə ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪhaɪn hɝ. hi wɑz ə hɛd tɔlɝ ðən ʃi ən ə lɪɾəl oʊldɝ, bʌɾ ɪz feɪs ən hɛɹ mɑɹkt ɪm əz əɹ kloʊs kɪn. hɪz koʊɾ ən kloʊk wɝ ɹɛɾ ən waɪɾ ən ɡoʊld, ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ən bɹoʊkeɪɾɪd, ən fəɹ ə meɪl ivən mɔɹ ɔɹneɪt ðən hɝz. ðəɾ ɪnkɹist ɹændz æŋzaɪəɾi. oʊnli ɑn ə fistdeɪ wəɾ ɛni ɔɹɾənɛɹi mæn dʒɹɛs ɪn ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ðæt, ən nɛvɝ wɪð ðət mʌtʃ ɡɹænduɹ. ðɪs wɑz noʊ pʌblɪk pɑɹk. pɝhæps ðə ɡɑɹdz wɝ tu bɪzi tə bɑðɝ wɪð tʃɹɛspæsɝz.

A scrabbling sound came from up in the tree and bits of bark fell, followed by a boy dropping lightly to the ground behind her. He was a head taller than she and a little older, but his face and hair marked him as her close kin. His coat and cloak were red and white and gold, embroidered and brocaded, and for a male even more ornate than hers. That increased Rand's anxiety. Only on a feastday would any ordinary man dress in anything like that, and never with that much grandeur. This was no public park. Perhaps the Guards were too busy to bother with trespassers.

ðə bɔɪ stʌɾid ɹænd oʊvɝ ðə ɡɝlz ʃoʊldɝ, fɪŋɡɝɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ əɾ ɪz weɪst. ɪt simd mɔɹ ə nɝvəs hæbət ðən ɛni θɔt ðəɾ i maɪt juz ɪt. nɑt kəmplitli, ðoʊ. ðə bɔɪ hæd ðə seɪm sɛlf-pəzɛʃən əz ðə ɡɝl, ən ðeɪ boʊθ lʊkt əɾ ɪm əz ɪf i wɝ ə pʌzəl tə bi sɑlvd. hi hæd ði ɑd filɪŋ ðət ðə ɡɝl, ət list, wɑz kɑɾə loʊɡɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪm fɹəm ðə kəndɪʃən ə hɪz buts tə ðə steɪɾ ə hɪz kloʊk.

The boy studied Rand over the girl's shoulder, fingering the dagger at his waist. It seemed more a nervous habit than any thought that he might use it. Not completely, though. The boy had the same self-possession as the girl, and they both looked at him as if he were a puzzle to be solved. He had the odd feeling that the girl, at least, was cata loguing everything about him from the condition of his boots to the state of his cloak.

"wi wɪl nɛvɝ hɪɹ ði ɛn ə ðɪs, ɪleɪn, ɪf mʌðɝ faɪnz aʊt," ðə bɔɪ sɛd sʌɾənli. "ʃi toʊld əs tə steɪ ɪn əɹ ɹumz, bʌt jə dʒʌs hæd tə ɡɛɾ ə lʊk ət lɑɡən, dɪdn ju? naʊ lʊk wʌɾ ɪts ɡɑɾ ʌs."

"We will never hear the end of this, Elayne, if mother finds out," the boy said suddenly. "She told us to stay in our rooms, but you just had to get a look at Logain, didn't you? Now look what it has got us."

"bi kwaɪət, ɡɔɪn." ʃi wɑz klɪɹli ðə jʌŋɡɝ ə ðə tu, bʌt ʃi spoʊk əz ðoʊ ʃi tʊk ɪt fəɹ ɡɹæntəd ðəɾ i wəɾ oʊbeɪ. ðə bɔɪz feɪs stʃɹʌɡəld əz ɪf i hæd mɔɹ tə seɪ, bʌt tə ɹændz sɝpɹaɪz i hɛld ɪz pis. "ɑɹ jə ɔl ɹaɪt?" ʃi sɛd sʌɾənli.

"Be quiet, Gawyn." She was clearly the younger of the two, but she spoke as though she took it for granted that he would obey. The boy's face struggled as if he had more to say, but to Rand's surprise he held his peace. "Are you all right?" she said suddenly.

ɪt tʊk ɹænd ə mɪnət tə ɹilaɪz ʃi wɑz spikɪŋ tə hɪm. wən i dɪd, hi tʃɹaɪd tə stʃɹʌɡəl tə hɪz fit. "aɪm faɪn. aɪ dʒʌst - " hi tɑɾɝd, ən ɪz lɛɡz ɡeɪv weɪ. hi sæt bæk daʊn hɑɹd. hɪz hɛd swæm. "aɪl dʒʌs klaɪm bæk oʊvɝ ðə wɔl," hi mʌɾɝd. hi ətɛmptəd tə stæn əɡɛn, bʌt ʃi pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, pɹɛsɪŋ ɪm daʊn. hi wɑz soʊ dɪzi ðə slaɪt pɹɛʃɝ wɑz ɪnʌf tə hoʊld ɪm ɪn pleɪs.

It took Rand a minute to realize she was speaking to him. When he did, he tried to struggle to his feet. "I'm fine. I just - " He tottered, and his legs gave way. He sat back down hard. His head swam. "I'll just climb back over the wall," he muttered. He attempted to stand again, but she put a hand on his shoulder, pressing him down. He was so dizzy the slight pressure was enough to hold him in place.

"ju ɑɹ hɝt." ɡɹeɪsfəli ʃi nɛl bɪsaɪd hɪm. hɝ fɪŋɡɝz dʒɛnli pɑɹɾəd ðə blʌd-mæɾɪd hɛɹ ɑn ðə lɛf saɪɾ ə hɪz hɛd. "ju mʌst əv stʃɹʌk ə bɹæntʃ kʌmɪŋ daʊn. jəl bi lʌki ɪf jə dɪdn bɹeɪk ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən jəɹ skælp. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk aɪ ɛvɝ sɔ ɛniwʌn əz skɪlfəl ət klaɪmɪŋ əz ju, bʌt jə doʊn də soʊ wɛl fɔlɪŋ."

"You are hurt." Gracefully she knelt beside him. Her fingers gently parted the blood-matted hair on the left side of his head. "You must have struck a branch coming down. You will be lucky if you didn't break anything more than your scalp. I don't think I ever saw anyone as skillful at climbing as you, but you don't do so well falling."

"jul ɡɛt blʌɾ ɑn jəɹ hænz," hi sɛd, dʒɹɔɪŋ bæk.

"You'll get blood on your hands," he said, drawing back.

fɝmli ʃi pʊld ɪz hɛd bæk tə wɛɹ ʃi kəd ɡɛɾ əɾ ɪt. "hoʊl stɪl." ʃi dɪd nɑt spik ʃɑɹpli, bʌɾ əɡɛn ðəɹ wɑz ðət noʊɾ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs əz ɪf ʃi ɪkspɛktəd tə bi oʊbeɪd. "ɪt dʌz nɑt lʊk tu bæd, θæŋk ðə laɪt." fɹəm pɑkəts ɑn ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə hɝ kloʊk ʃi bɪɡæn teɪkɪŋ aʊɾ ən ɝeɪ ʌv taɪni vaɪəlz ən twɪstəd pækɪts ə peɪpɝ, fɪnɪʃɪŋ wɪð ə hændfʊl ʌv wɑɾəd bændɪdʒ.

Firmly she pulled his head back to where she could get at it. "Hold still." She did not speak sharply, but again there was that note in her voice as if she expected to be obeyed. "It does not look too bad, thank the Light." From pockets on the inside of her cloak she began taking out an array of tiny vials and twisted packets of paper, finishing with a handful of wadded bandage.

hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə kəlɛkʃən ɪn əmeɪzmənt. ɪt wɑz ðə sɔɹɾ ə θɪŋ i wʊɾə ɪkspɛktəɾ ə wɪzdəm tə kæɹi, nɑt sʌmwʌn dʒɹɛst əz ʃi wɑz. ʃi hæd ɡɑɾən blʌɾ ɑn əɹ fɪŋɡɝz, hi sɔ, bʌɾ ɪt dɪd nɑt sim tə bɑðɝ hɝ.

He stared at the collection in amazement. It was the sort of thing he would have expected a Wisdom to carry, not someone dressed as she was. She had gotten blood on her fingers, he saw, but it did not seem to bother her.

"ɡɪv mi jəɹ wɔɾɝ flæsk, ɡɔɪn," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ nid tə wɑʃ ðɪs."

"Give me your water flask, Gawyn," she said. "I need to wash this."

ðə bɔɪ ʃi kɔld ɡɔɪn ənfæsən ə lɛðɝ bɑɾəl fɹəm ɪz bɛlt ən hændəɾ ɪt tə hɝ, ðən skwɑɾɪd izəli ət ɹændz fit wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ ɑn ɪz niz. ɪleɪn wɛn əbaʊt wʌt ʃi wɑz duɪŋ ɪn ə vɛɹi wɝkmænlaɪk mænɝ. hi dɪd nɑt flɪntʃ ət ðə stɪŋ ə koʊld wɔɾɝ wən ʃi wɑʃt ðə kʌɾ ɪn ɪz skælp, bʌt ʃi hɛl ðə tɑp ə hɪz hɛd wɪð wʌn hæn əz ɪf ʃi ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪm tə tʃɹaɪ tə pʊl əweɪ əɡɛn ən wəɾ əv nʌn ʌv ɪt. ði ɔɪnmənt ʃi smuðd ɑn æftɝ, fɹəm wʌn ə hɝ smɔl vaɪəlz, suðd ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz wʌn ə nɪneɪivz pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz wəd hæv.

The boy she called Gawyn unfastened a leather bottle from his belt and handed it to her, then squatted easily at Rand's feet with his arms folded on his knees. Elayne went about what she was doing in a very workmanlike manner. He did not flinch at the sting of cold water when she washed the cut in his scalp, but she held the top of his head with one hand as if she expected him to try to pull away again and would have none of it. The ointment she smoothed on after, from one of her small vials, soothed almost as much as one of Nynaeve's preparations would have.

ɡɔɪn smaɪld əɾ ɪm əz ʃi wɝkt, ə kɑmɪŋ smaɪl, əz ɪf hi, tu, ɪkspɛktəd ɹænd tə dʒɝk əweɪ ən meɪbi ivən ɹʌn. "ʃiz ɔlweɪz faɪndɪŋ stʃɹeɪ kæts ən bɝdz wɪð bɹoʊkən wɪŋz. jə ɑɹ ðə fɝs hjumən biɪŋ ʃiz hæd tə wɝk ɑn." hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən æɾəd, "du nɑt bi əfɛndəd. aɪm nɑt kɔlɪŋ jə ə stʃɹeɪ." ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ən əpɑlədʒi, dʒʌst ə steɪtmən ə fækt.

Gawyn smiled at him as she worked, a calming smile, as if he, too, expected Rand to jerk away and maybe even run. "She's always finding stray cats and birds with broken wings. You are the first human being she has had to work on." He hesitated, then added, "Do not be offended. I am not calling you a stray." It was not an apology, just a statement of fact.

"noʊ əfɛns teɪkən," ɹænd sɛd stɪfli. bʌt ðə pɛɹ wɝ æktɪŋ əz ɪf i wɝ ə skɪɾɪʃ hɔɹs.

"No offense taken," Rand said stiffly. But the pair were acting as if he were a skittish horse.

"ʃi dʌz noʊ wʌt ʃiz duɪŋ," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ʃi hæz hæd ðə bɛs titʃɝz. soʊ də nɑt fɪɹ, jə ɑɹ ɪn ɡʊd hænz."

"She does know what she is doing," Gawyn said. "She has had the best teachers. So do not fear, you are in good hands."

ɪleɪn pɹɛst səm ə ðə bændeɪdʒɪŋ əɡɛnst ɪz tɛmpəl ən pʊld ə sɪlk skɑɹf fɹəm əɹ bɛlt, blu ən kɹim ən ɡoʊld. fəɹ ɛni ɡɝl ɪn ɛmənz fild ɪt wʊɾə bɪn ə tʃɹɛʒɝd fistdeɪ klɔθ. ɪleɪn dɛfli bɪɡæn waɪndɪŋ ɪɾ ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd tə hoʊl ðə wɑɾ ə bændɪdʒ ɪn pleɪs.

Elayne pressed some of the bandaging against his temple and pulled a silk scarf from her belt, blue and cream and gold. For any girl in Emond's Field it would have been a treasured feastday cloth. Elayne deftly began winding it around his head to hold the wad of bandage in place.

"ju kæn jus ðæt," hi pɹətɛstəd.

"You can't use that," he protested.

ʃi wɛn ɑn waɪndɪŋ. "aɪ toʊl jə tə hoʊl stɪl," ʃi sɛd kɑmli.

She went on winding. "I told you to hold still," she said calmly.

ɹænd lʊkt ət ɡɔɪn. "dʌz ʃi ɔlweɪz ɪkspɛkt ɛvɹibɑɾi tə də wʌt ʃi tɛlz ðɛm?"

Rand looked at Gawyn. "Does she always expect everybody to do what she tells them?"

ə flæʃ ə sɝpɹaɪz kɹɔs ðə jʌŋ mænz feɪs, ən ɪz maʊθ taɪɾənd wɪð əmjuzmənt. "moʊst ə ðə taɪm ʃi dʌz. ən moʊst ə ðə taɪm ðeɪ du."

A flash of surprise crossed the young man's face, and his mouth tightened with amusement. "Most of the time she does. And most of the time they do."

"hoʊl ðɪs," ɪleɪn sɛd. "pʊt jəɹ hæn ðəɹ waɪl aɪ taɪ - " ʃi ɪkskleɪmd ət ðə saɪɾ ə hɪz hænz. "ju dɪd nɑt də ðət fɔlɪŋ. klaɪmɪŋ wɛɹ jə ʃəd nɑɾ əv bɪn klaɪmɪŋ ɪz mɔɹ laɪk ɪt." kwɪkli fɪnɪʃɪŋ əɹ nɑt, ʃi tɝn ɪz hænz pɑmz ʌpwɝɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɝsɛlf əbaʊt haʊ lɪɾəl wɔɾɝ wɑz lɛft. ðə wɑʃɪŋ meɪd ðə læsɝeɪʃənz bɝn, bʌɾ əɹ tʌtʃ wɑz sɝpɹaɪzɪŋli dɛləkət. "hoʊl stɪl, ðɪs taɪm."

"Hold this," Elayne said. "Put your hand there while I tie - " She exclaimed at the sight of his hands. "You did not do that falling. Climbing where you should not have been climbing is more like it." Quickly finishing her knot, she turned his hands palms upward in front of him, muttering to herself about how little water was left. The washing made the lacerations burn, but her touch was surprisingly delicate. "Hold still, this time."

ðə vaɪəl ʌv ɔɪnmənt wɑz pɹədust əɡɛn. ʃi spɹɛɾ ɪt θɪnli əlɔŋ ðə skɹeɪps, ɔl ə hɝ ətɛnʃən əpɛɹənli ɑn ɹʌbɪŋ ɪɾ ɪn wɪθaʊt hɝɾɪŋ hɪm. ə kulnəs spɹɛd θɹu hɪz hænz, əz ɪf ʃi wɝ ɹʌbɪŋ ðə tɔɹn pleɪsəz əweɪ.

The vial of ointment was produced again. She spread it thinly along the scrapes, all of her attention apparently on rubbing it in without hurting him. A coolness spread through his hands, as if she were rubbing the torn places away.

"moʊst ə ðə taɪm ðeɪ də ɪɡzækli wʌt ʃi sɛz," ɡɔɪn wɛn ɑn wɪð ən əfɛkʃənət ɡɹɪn ət ðə tɑp ə hɝ hɛd. "moʊs pipəl. nɑt mʌðɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. əɹ ɪleɪɾə. ən nɑt lini. lini wɑz əɹ nɝs. jə kænt ɡɪv ɔɹɾɝz tə sʌmwʌn u swɪtʃt jə fəɹ stilɪŋ fɪɡz wən jə wɝ lɪɾəl. ən ivən nɑt soʊ lɪɾəl." ɪleɪn ɹeɪzd əɹ hɛd lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɡɪv ɪm ə deɪnʒɝəs lʊk. hi klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ ən kɛɹfəli blæŋkt ɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən bɪfɔɹ hɝiɪŋ ɑn. "ænd ɡɛɹɪθ, ʌv kɔɹs. noʊ wʌn ɡɪvz ɔɹɾɝz tə ɡɛɹɪθ."

"Most of the time they do exactly what she says," Gawyn went on with an affectionate grin at the top of her head. "Most people. Not Mother, of course. Or Elaida. And not Lini. Lini was her nurse. You can't give orders to someone who switched you for stealing figs when you were little. And even not so little." Elayne raised her head long enough to give him a dangerous look. He cleared his throat and carefully blanked his expression before hurrying on. "And Gareth, of course. No one gives orders to Gareth."

"nɑɾ ivən mʌðɝ," ɪleɪn sɛd, bɛndɪŋ əɹ hɛd bæk oʊvɝ ɹændz hænz. "ʃi meɪks sədʒɛstʃənz, ən i ɔlweɪz dʌz wʌt ʃi sədʒɛsts, bʌɾ aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ əɹ ɡɪv ɪm ə kəmænd." ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

"Not even Mother," Elayne said, bending her head back over Rand's hands. "She makes suggestions, and he always does what she suggests, but I've never heard her give him a command." She shook her head.

"aɪ doʊnt noʊ waɪ ðəɾ ɔlweɪz sɝpɹaɪzəz ju," ɡɔɪn ænsɝd hɝ. "ivən jə doʊn tʃɹaɪ tɛlɪŋ ɡɛɹɪθ wʌt tə du. hiz sɝv θɹi kwinz ən bɪn kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl, ən fɝs pɹɪns ɹidʒənt, fəɹ tu. aɪ dɛɹɪs ðəɹ ɑɹ səm θɪŋk hiz mɔɹ ə sɪmbəl ə ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ ðən ðə kwin ɪz."

"I don't know why that always surprises you," Gawyn answered her. "Even you don't try telling Gareth what to do. He's served three Queens and been Captain-General, and First Prince Regent, for two. I daresay there are some think he's more a symbol of the Throne of Andor than the Queen is."

"mʌðɝ ʃəd ɡoʊ əhɛɾ ən mɛɹi hɪm," ʃi sɛɾ æbsənli. hɝ ətɛnʃən wɑz ɑn ɹændz hænz. "ʃi wɑns tə; ʃi kæn haɪɾ ɪt fɹəm mi. ən ɪt wəd sɑlv soʊ mɛni pɹɑbləmz."

"Mother should go ahead and marry him," she said absently. Her attention was on Rand's hands. "She wants to; she can't hide it from me. And it would solve so many problems."

ɡɔɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "wʌn ə ðɛm mʌs bɛn fɝst. mʌðɝ kænɑt, ən ɡɛɹɪθ wɪl nɑt."

Gawyn shook his head. "One of them must bend first. Mother cannot, and Gareth will not."

"ɪf ʃi kəmændəd hɪm. . . ."

"If she commanded him. . . ."

"hi wəɾ oʊbeɪ. aɪ θɪŋk. bʌt ʃi woʊnt. jə noʊ ʃi woʊnt."

"He would obey. I think. But she won't. You know she won't."

əbɹʌpli ðeɪ tɝn tə stɛɹ ət ɹænd. hi hæd ðə filɪŋ ðeɪ hæd fɝɡɑɾən i wɑz ðɛɹ. "hu . . . ?" hi hæd tə stɑp tə wɛɾ ɪz lɪps. "hu ɪz jəɹ mʌðɝ?"

Abruptly they turned to stare at Rand. He had the feeling they had forgotten he was there. "Who . . . ?" He had to stop to wet his lips. "Who is your mother?"

ɪleɪnz aɪz waɪɾənd ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, bʌt ɡɔɪn spoʊk ɪn ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi toʊn ðət meɪɾ ɪz wɝdz ɔl ðə mɔɹ dʒɑɹɪŋ. "mɔɹɡeɪs, baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪs ə ðə laɪt, kwin ʌv ændɝ, dɪfɛndɝ ə ðə ɹɛlm, pɹətɛktɝ ə ðə pipəl, haɪ siɾ ə ðə haʊs tʃɹəkənd."

Elayne's eyes widened in surprise, but Gawyn spoke in an ordinary tone that made his words all the more jarring. "Morgase, by the Grace of the Light, Queen of Andor, Defender of the Realm, Protector of the People, High Seat of the House Trakand."

"ðə kwin," ɹænd mʌɾɝd, ʃɑk spɹɛɾɪŋ θɹu hɪm ɪn weɪvz ə nʌmnəs. fəɹ ə mɪnəɾ i θɔɾ ɪz hɛd wɑz gɑnə bɪɡɪn spɪnɪŋ əɡɛn. doʊn ətʃɹækt ɛni ətɛnʃən. dʒʌs fɔl ɪndə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹɾən ən lɛt ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ tɛn jəɹ kʌts laɪk ə hɛdʒ-dɑktɝ. hi wɑntəd tə læf, ən nu ɪt fəɹ ðə fɹɪnʒɪz ə pænɪk.

"The Queen," Rand muttered, shock spreading through him in waves of numbness. For a minute he thought his head was going to begin spinning again. Don't attract any attention. Just fall into the Queen's garden and let the Daughter-Heir tend your cuts like a hedge-doctor. He wanted to laugh, and knew it for the fringes of panic.

dʒɹɔɪŋ ə dip bɹɛθ, hi skɹæmbəl heɪstəli tə hɪz fit. hi hɛl hɪmsɛlf taɪtli ɪn ɹeɪn əɡɛns ði ɝdʒ tə ɹʌn, bʌt ðə nid tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɪl hɪm, tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls dɪskʌvɝɾ ɪm ðɛɹ.

Drawing a deep breath, he scrambled hastily to his feet. He held himself tightly in rein against the urge to run, but the need to get away filled him, to get away before anyone else discovered him there.

ɪleɪn ən ɡɔɪn wɑtʃt ɪm kɑmli, ən wən i lɛpt ʌp ðeɪ ɹoʊz ɡɹeɪsfəli, nɑt hɝiɾ ɪn ðə list. hi pʊɾ ʌp ə hæn tə pʊl ðə skɑɹf fɹəm ɪz hɛd, ən ɪleɪn sizd ɪz ɛlboʊ. "stɑp ðæt. jəl stɑɹt ðə bliɾɪŋ əɡɛn." hɝ vɔɪs wɑz stɪl kɑm, stɪl ʃʊɹ ðəɾ i wəd də əz i wɑz toʊld.

Elayne and Gawyn watched him calmly, and when he leaped up they rose gracefully, not hurried in the least. He put up a hand to pull the scarf from his head, and Elayne seized his elbow. "Stop that. You will start the bleeding again." Her voice was still calm, still sure that he would do as he was told.

"aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ," ɹænd sɛd. "aɪl dʒʌs klaɪm bæk oʊvɝ ðə wɔl ən - "

"I have to go," Rand said. "I'll just climb back over the wall and - "

"ju ɹɪli dɪdnt noʊ." fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ʃi simd əz stɑɹɾəld əz i wɑz. "du jə min jə klaɪmd ʌp ɑn ðət wɔl tə si lɑɡən wɪθaʊɾ ivən noʊɪŋ wɛɹ jə wɝ? jə cʊɾə ɡɑɾən ə mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ vju daʊn ɪn ðə stʃɹits."

"You really didn't know." For the first time she seemed as startled as he was. "Do you mean you climbed up on that wall to see Logain without even knowing where you were? You could have gotten a much better view down in the streets."

"aɪ . . . aɪ doʊn laɪk kɹaʊdz," hi mʌmbəld. hi skɛtʃt ə baʊ tə itʃ ə ðɛm. "ɪf jəl pɑɹɾən mi, ɑ . . . maɪ leɪɾi." ɪn ðə stɔɹiz, ɹɔɪəl kɔɹts wɝ fʊl ə pipəl ɔl kɔlɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ lɔɹɾ ən leɪɾi ən ɹɔɪəl haɪnəs ən mædʒəsti, bʌɾ ɪf i hæɾ ɛvɝ hɝd ðə kɝɛk fɔɹm ʌv ədʒɹɛs fəɹ ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ, hi kəd nɑt θɪŋk klɪɹli ɪnʌf tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ. hi kəd nɑt θɪŋk klɪɹli əbaʊɾ ɛniθɪŋ bɪɑn ðə nid tə bi fɑɹ əweɪ. "ɪf jəl pɑɹɾən mi, əl dʒʌs liv naʊ. ɑ . . . θæŋk jə fəɹ ðə. . . ." hi tʌtʃt ðə skɑɹf ɝaʊn ɪz hɛd. "θæŋk ju."

"I . . . I don't like crowds," he mumbled. He sketched a bow to each of them. "If you'll pardon me, ah . . . my Lady." In the stories, royal courts were full of people all calling one another Lord and Lady and Royal Highness and Majesty, but if he had ever heard the correct form of address for the Daughter-Heir, he could not think clearly enough to remember. He could not think clearly about anything beyond the need to be far away. "If you will pardon me, I'll just leave now. Ah . . . thank you for the. . . ." He touched the scarf around his head. "Thank you."

"wɪθaʊɾ ivən tɛlɪŋ əs jəɹ neɪm?" ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ə pʊɹ peɪmən fəɹ ɪleɪnz kɛɹ. aɪv bɪn wʌndɝɪŋ əbaʊt ju. jə saʊn laɪk ən ændɔɝmən, ðoʊ nɑɾ ə keɪɛmlaɪnɝ, sɝɾənli, bʌt jə lʊk laɪk. . . . wɛl, jə noʊ əɹ neɪmz. kɝɾəsi wəd sədʒɛs jə ɡɪv əs jʊɹz."

"Without even telling us your name?" Gawyn said. "A poor payment for Elayne's care. I've been wondering about you. You sound like an Andorman, though not a Caemlyner, certainly, but you look like. . . . Well, you know our names. Courtesy would suggest you give us yours."

lʊkɪŋ lɔŋɪŋli ət ðə wɔl, ɹænd ɡeɪv ɪz ɹaɪt neɪm bɪfɔɹ i θɔt wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ, ən ivən æɾəd, "fɹʌm ɛmənz fild, ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz."

Looking longingly at the wall, Rand gave his right name before he thought what he was doing, and even added, "From Emond's Field, in the Two Rivers."

"fɹʌm ðə wɛst," ɡɔɪn mɝmɝd. "vɛɹi fɑɹ tə ðə wɛst."

"From the west," Gawyn murmured. "Very far to the west."

ɹænd lʊkt ɝaʊn əɾ ɪm ʃɑɹpli. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə noʊɾ ə sɝpɹaɪz ɪn ðə jʌŋ mænz vɔɪs, ən ɹænd kɑt səm ʌv ɪt stɪl ɑn ɪz feɪs wən i tɝnd. ɡɔɪn ɹipleɪst ɪt wɪð ə plɛzən smaɪl soʊ kwɪkli, ðoʊ, ðəɾ i ɔlmoʊs daʊɾɪd wʌɾ i hæd sin.

Rand looked around at him sharply. There had been a note of surprise in the young man's voice, and Rand caught some of it still on his face when he turned. Gawyn replaced it with a pleasant smile so quickly, though, that he almost doubted what he had seen.

"təbæk ən wʊl," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "aɪ hæv tə noʊ ðə pɹɪnsəpəl pɹɑɾəkts ʌv ɛvɹi pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɹɛlm. ʌv ɛvɹi lænd, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. pɑɹɾ ə maɪ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. pɹɪnsəpəl pɹɑɾəkts ən kɹæfs, ən wʌt ðə pipəl ɑɹ laɪk. ðɛɹ kʌstəmz, ðɛɹ stʃɹɛŋkθs ən wiknəsəz. ɪts sɛd tu ɹɪvɝz pipəl ɑɹ stʌbɝn. ðeɪ kən bi lɛd, ɪf ðeɪ θɪŋk jə ɑɹ wɝði, bʌt ðə hɑɹɾɝ jə tʃɹaɪ tə pʊʃ ðɛm, ðə hɑɹɾɝ ðeɪ dɪɡ ɪn. ɪleɪn ɔt tə tʃuz əɹ hʌzbən fɹəm ðɛɹ. ɪɾəl teɪk ə mæn wɪð ə wɪl laɪk stoʊn tə kip fɹəm biɪŋ tʃɹæmpəl baɪ hɝ."

"Tabac and wool," Gawyn said. "I have to know the principal products of every part of the Realm. Of every land, for that matter. Part of my training. Principal products and crafts, and what the people are like. Their customs, their strengths and weaknesses. It's said Two Rivers people are stubborn. They can be led, if they think you are worthy, but the harder you try to push them, the harder they dig in. Elayne ought to choose her husband from there. It'll take a man with a will like stone to keep from being trampled by her."

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət hɪm. ɪleɪn wɑz stɛɹɪŋ, tu. ɡɔɪn lʊkt əz mʌtʃ ʌndɝ kəntʃɹoʊl əz ɛvɝ, bʌɾ i wɑz bæbəlɪŋ. waɪ?

Rand stared at him. Elayne was staring, too. Gawyn looked as much under control as ever, but he was babbling. Why?

"wʌts ðɪs?"

"What's this?"

ɔl θɹi ʌv əm dʒʌmpt ət ðə sʌɾən vɔɪs, ən spʌn tə feɪs ɪt.

All three of them jumped at the sudden voice, and spun to face it.

ðə jʌŋ mæn u stʊd ðəɹ wɑz ðə hænsoʊməs mæn ɹænd hæɾ ɛvɝ sin, ɔlmoʊs tu hænsəm fəɹ mæskjəlɪnəɾi. hi wɑz tɔl ən slɛndɝ, bʌɾ ɪz muvməns spoʊk ʌv wɪpkɔɹd stʃɹɛŋkθ ən ə ʃʊɹ kɑnfəɾəns. dɑɹk ə hɛɹ ən aɪ, hi wɔɹ ɪz kloʊðz, oʊnli ə lɪɾəl lɛs ɪlæbɹəɾ ɪn ɹɛɾ ən waɪt ðən ɡɔɪnz, əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ə noʊ ɪmpɔɹɾəns. wʌn hæn ɹɛstəɾ ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt, ən ɪz aɪz wɝ stɛɾi ɑn ɹænd.

The young man who stood there was the handsomest man Rand had ever seen, almost too handsome for masculinity. He was tall and slender, but his movements spoke of whipcord strength and a sure confidence. Dark of hair and eye, he wore his clothes, only a little less elaborate in red and white than Gawyn's, as if they were of no importance. One hand rested on his sword hilt, and his eyes were steady on Rand.

"stæn əweɪ fɹəm hɪm, ɪleɪn," ðə mæn sɛd. "ju, tu, ɡɔɪn."

"Stand away from him, Elayne," the man said. "You, too, Gawyn."

ɪleɪn stɛpt ɪn fɹʌn ə ɹænd, bɪtwin ɪm ən ðə nukʌmɝ, hɛd haɪ ən əz kɑnfəɾənt əz ɛvɝ. "hi ɪz ə lɔɪəl sʌbʒɪkt ʌv əɹ mʌðɝ, ən ə ɡʊd kwinz mæn. ən hiz ʌndɝ maɪ pɹətɛkʃən, ɡɑləd."

Elayne stepped in front of Rand, between him and the newcomer, head high and as confident as ever. "He is a loyal subject of our mother, and a good Queen's man. And he is under my protection, Galad."

ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌɾ i hæd hɝd fɹəm mæstɝ kɪntʃ, ən sɪns fɹəm mæstɝ ɡɪl. ɡɑleɪdɛdʒɹəd dəmədʒɹd wɑz ɪleɪnz hæf-bɹʌðɝ, ɪleɪnz ən ɡɔɪnz, ɪf i ɹɪmɛmbɝd kɝɛkli; ðə θɹi ʃɛɹd ðə seɪm fɑðɝ. mæstɝ kɪntʃ maɪt nɑɾ əv laɪk tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl dəmədʒɹd tu wɛl - niðɝ dɪɾ ɛniwʌn ɛls ðəɾ i hæd hɝd - bʌt ðə sʌn wɑz wɛl θɔɾ ə baɪ wɛɹɝz ə ðə ɹɛɾ ən ðə waɪɾ əlaɪk, ɪf tɔk ɪn ðə sɪɾi wɑz ɛni ɡaɪd.

Rand tried to remember what he had heard from Master Kinch, and since from Master Gill. Galadedrid Damodred was Elayne's half-brother, Elayne's and Gawyn's, if he remembered correctly; the three shared the same father. Master Kinch might not have liked Taringail Damodred too well - neither did anyone else that he had heard - but the son was well thought of by wearers of the red and the white alike, if talk in the city was any guide.

"aɪ æm əwɛɹ ə jəɹ fɑndnəs fəɹ stʃɹeɪz, ɪleɪn," ðə slɛndɝ mæn sɛd ɹizənəbli, "bʌt ðə fɛloʊ ɪz ɑɹmd, ən i hɑɹdli lʊks ɹɛpjəɾəbəl. ɪn ðiz deɪz, wi kænɑt bi tu kɛɹfəl. ɪf hiz ə lɔɪəl kwinz mæn, wʌɾ ɪz i duɪŋ hɪɹ wɛɹ i dʌz nɑt bɪlɔŋ? ɪts izi ɪnʌf tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə ɹæpɪŋz ɑn ə sɔɹd, ɪleɪn."

"I am aware of your fondness for strays, Elayne," the slender man said reasonably, "but the fellow is armed, and he hardly looks reputable. In these days, we cannot be too careful. If he's a loyal Queen's man, what is he doing here where he does not belong? It is easy enough to change the wrappings on a sword, Elayne."

"hi ɪz hɪɹ əz maɪ ɡɛst, ɡɑləd, ən aɪ vaʊtʃ fəɹ hɪm. əɹ əv jə əpɔɪntəd jɝsɛlf maɪ nɝs, tə dɪsaɪd hum aɪ meɪ tɔk tə, ən wɛn?"

"He is here as my guest, Galad, and I vouch for him. Or have you appointed yourself my nurse, to decide whom I may talk to, and when?"

hɝ vɔɪs wɑz ɹɪtʃ wɪð skɔɹn, bʌt ɡɑləd simd ənmuvd. "ju noʊ aɪ meɪk noʊ kleɪmz fəɹ kəntʃɹoʊl oʊvɝ jəɹ ækʃənz, ɪleɪn, bʌt ðɪs . . . ɡɛst ə jʊɹz ɪz nɑt pɹɑpɝ, ən jə noʊ ðəɾ əz wɛl əz aɪ. ɡɔɪn, hɛlp mi kənvɪns hɝ. əɹ mʌðɝ wəd - "

Her voice was rich with scorn, but Galad seemed unmoved. "You know I make no claims for control over your actions, Elayne, but this . . . guest of yours is not proper, and you know that as well as I. Gawyn, help me convince her. Our mother would - "

"ɪnʌf!" ɪleɪn snæpt. "ju ɑɹ ɹaɪt ðət juv noʊ seɪ oʊvɝ maɪ ækʃənz, nɔɹ əv jə ɛni ɹaɪt tə dʒʌdʒ ðɛm. jə meɪ liv mi. naʊ!"

"Enough!" Elayne snapped. "You are right that you have no say over my actions, nor have you any right to judge them. You may leave me. Now!"

ɡɑləd ɡeɪv ɡɔɪn ə ɹufəl lʊk; ət wʌn ən ðə seɪm taɪm ɪt sim tə æsk fəɹ hɛlp waɪl seɪɪŋ ðəɾ ɪleɪn wɑz tu hɛdstʃɹɔŋ tə bi hɛlpt. ɪleɪnz feɪs dɑɹkənd, bʌt dʒʌst əz ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ əɡɛn, hi baʊd, ɪn ɔl fɔɹmæləɾi jɛt wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪs ʌv ə kæt, tʊk ə stɛp bæk, ðən tɝn ən stʃɹoʊd daʊn ðə peɪv pæθ, hɪz lɔŋ lɛɡz kæɹiɪŋ ɪm kwɪkli aʊɾ ə saɪt bɪɑn ði ɑɹbɝ.

Galad gave Gawyn a rueful look; at one and the same time it seemed to ask for help while saying that Elayne was too headstrong to be helped. Elayne's face darkened, but just as she opened her mouth again, he bowed, in all formality yet with the grace of a cat, took a step back, then turned and strode down the paved path, his long legs carrying him quickly out of sight beyond the arbor.

"aɪ heɪt hɪm," ɪleɪn bɹiðd. "hi ɪz vaɪl ən fʊl ʌv ɛnvi."

"I hate him," Elayne breathed. "He is vile and full of envy."

"ðɛɹ jə ɡoʊ tu fɑɹ, ɪleɪn," ɡɔɪn sɛd. "ɡɑləd dʌz nɑt noʊ ðə minɪŋ ʌv ɛnvi. twaɪs hiz seɪv maɪ laɪf, wɪð nʌn tə noʊ ɪf i hɛld ɪz hænd. ɪf i hæd nɑt, hi wəd bi jəɹ fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹɾ ɪn maɪ pleɪs."

"There you go too far, Elayne," Gawyn said. "Galad does not know the meaning of envy. Twice he has saved my life, with none to know if he held his hand. If he had not, he would be your First Prince of the Sword in my place."

"nɛvɝ, ɡɔɪn. aɪ wəd tʃuz ɛniwʌn bɪfɔɹ ɡɑləd. ɛniwʌn. ðə loʊəst steɪbəlbɔɪ." sʌɾənli ʃi smaɪld ən ɡeɪv əɹ bɹʌðɝ ə mɑk-stɝn lʊk. "ju seɪ aɪm fɑn ʌv ɡɪvɪŋ ɔɹɾɝz. wɛl, aɪ kəmæn jə tə lɛt nʌθɪŋ hæpən tə ju. aɪ kəmæn jə tə bi maɪ fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd wən aɪ teɪk ðə θɹoʊn - ðə laɪt sɛn ðət deɪ ɪz fɑɹ ɔf! - ən tə lid ði ɑɹmiz ʌv ændɝ wɪð ðə sɔɹɾ ʌv ɑnɝ ɡɑləd kænɑt dʒɹim ʌv."

"Never, Gawyn. I would choose anyone before Galad. Anyone. The lowest stableboy." Suddenly she smiled and gave her brother a mock-stern look. "You say I am fond of giving orders. Well, I command you to let nothing happen to you. I command you to be my First Prince of the Sword when I take the throne - the light send that day is far off! - and to lead the armies of Andor with the sort of honor Galad cannot dream of."

"æz jə kəmænd, maɪ leɪɾi." ɡɔɪn læft, hɪz baʊ ə pɛɹəɾi ʌv ɡɑlədz.

"As you command, my Lady." Gawyn laughed, his bow a parody of Galad's.

ɪleɪn ɡeɪv ɹænd ə θɔtfəl fɹaʊn. "naʊ wi mʌst ɡɛt jə aʊɾ ə hɪɹ kwɪkli."

Elayne gave Rand a thoughtful frown. "Now we must get you out of here quickly."

"ɡɑləɾ ɔlweɪz dʌz ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ," ɡɔɪn ɪkspleɪnd, "ivən wən i ʃəd nɑt. ɪn ðɪs keɪs, faɪndɪŋ ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ ɪn ðə ɡɑɹɾənz, ðə ɹaɪt θɪŋ ɪz tə noʊɾəfaɪ ðə pæləs ɡɑɹdz. wɪtʃ aɪ səspɛk hiz ɑn ɪz weɪ tə də ɹaɪt ðɪs mɪnət."

"Galad always does the right thing," Gawyn explained, "even when he should not. In this case, finding a stranger in the gardens, the right thing is to notify the Palace guards. Which I suspect he is on his way to do right this minute."

"ðɛn ɪts taɪm aɪ wɑz bæk oʊvɝ ðə wɔl," ɹænd sɛd. ə faɪn deɪ fəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ənnoʊɾɪst! aɪ maɪɾ əz wɛl kæɹi ə saɪn! hi tɝn tə ðə wɔl, bʌɾ ɪleɪn kɑɾ ɪz ɑɹm.

"Then it's time I was back over the wall," Rand said. A fine day for going unnoticed! I might as well carry a sign! He turned to the wall, but Elayne caught his arm.

"nɑɾ æftɝ ðə tʃɹʌbəl aɪ wɛn tə wɪð jəɹ hænz. jəl oʊnli meɪk fɹɛʃ skɹeɪps ən ðən lɛt səm bæk-æli kɹoʊn pʊt ðə laɪt noʊz wʌɾ ɑn ðɛm. ðəɹ ɪz ə smɔl ɡeɪɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡɑɹɾən. ɪts oʊvɝɡɹoʊn, ən noʊ wʌn bʌt mi ivən ɹɪmɛmbɝz ɪts ðɛɹ."

"Not after the trouble I went to with your hands. You'll only make fresh scrapes and then let some back-alley crone put the Light knows what on them. There is a small gate on the other side of the garden. It's overgrown, and no one but me even remembers it's there."

sʌɾənli ɹænd hɝd buts paʊndɪŋ təwɔɹɾ əm oʊvɝ ðə sleɪt peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz.

Suddenly Rand heard boots pounding toward them over the slate paving stones.

"tu leɪt," ɡɔɪn mʌɾɝd. "hi mʌst əv stɑɹɾəd ɹʌnɪŋ əz sun əz i wɑz aʊɾ ʌv aɪʃɑt."

"Too late," Gawyn muttered. "He must have started running as soon as he was out of eyeshot."

ɪleɪn ɡɹaʊld ən oʊθ, ən ɹændz aɪbɹaʊz ʃɑɾ ʌp. hi hæd hɝd ðət wʌn fɹəm ðə steɪbəlmən ət ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ ən hæd bɪn ʃɑk ðɛn. ðə nɛks moʊmənt ʃi wɑz ɪn kul sɛlf-pəzɛʃən wʌns mɔɹ.

Elayne growled an oath, and Rand's eyebrows shot up. He had heard that one from the stablemen at The Queen's Blessing and had been shocked then. The next moment she was in cool self-possession once more.

ɡɔɪn ən ɪleɪn əpɪɹd kɑntɛn tə ɹɪmeɪn wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt meɪk hɪmsɛlf steɪ fəɹ ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz wɪð sətʃ ikwənɪmɪɾi. hi stɑɹɾəd wʌns mɔɹ fəɹ ðə wɔl, noʊɪŋ i wəd bi noʊ mɔɹ ðən hæfweɪ ʌp bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡɑɹdz ɝaɪvd, bʌɾ əneɪbəl tə stæn stɪl.

Gawyn and Elayne appeared content to remain where they were, but he could not make himself stay for the Queen's Guards with such equanimity. He started once more for the wall, knowing he would be no more than halfway up before the guards arrived, but unable to stand still.

bɪfɔɹ i hæd teɪkən θɹi stɛps ɹɛd-junəfɔɹmd mɛn bɝst ɪndə saɪt, bɹɛstpleɪts kætʃɪŋ ðə sʌn əz ðeɪ dæʃt ʌp ðə pæθ. ʌðɝz keɪm laɪk bɹeɪkɪŋ weɪvz ə skɑɹləɾ ən pɑlɪʃt stil, simɪŋli fɹəm ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən. səm hɛl dʒɹɔn sɔɹdz; ʌðɝz oʊnli weɪɾəd tə sɛt ðɛɹ buts bɪfɔɹ ɹeɪzɪŋ baʊz ən nɑkɪŋ fɛðɝd ʃæfs. bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɹd feɪsɡɑɹdz ɛvɹi aɪ wɑz ɡɹɪm, ən ɛvɹi bɹɔdhɛɾ æɹoʊ wɑz pɔɪntəɾ ənwəvɝɪŋli ət hɪm.

Before he had taken three steps red-uniformed men burst into sight, breastplates catching the sun as they dashed up the path. Others came like breaking waves of scarlet and polished steel, seemingly from every direction. Some held drawn swords; others only waited to set their boots before raising bows and nocking feathered shafts. Behind the barred faceguards every eye was grim, and every broadhead arrow was pointed unwaveringly at him.

ɪleɪn ən ɡɔɪn lɛpt əz wʌn, pʊɾɪŋ ðɛmsɛlvz bɪtwin ɪm ən ði æɹoʊz, ðɛɹ ɑɹmz spɹɛd tə kʌvɝ hɪm. hi stʊd vɛɹi stɪl ən kɛpt ɪz hænz ɪn pleɪn saɪt, əweɪ fɹəm ɪz sɔɹd.

Elayne and Gawyn leaped as one, putting themselves between him and the arrows, their arms spread to cover him. He stood very still and kept his hands in plain sight, away from his sword.

waɪl ðə θʌɾ ə buts ən ðə kɹik ə bɑstʃɹɪŋz stɪl hʌŋ ɪn ði ɛɹ, wʌn ə ðə soʊlʒɝz, wɪð ðə ɡoʊldən nɑɾ ʌv ən ɔfəsɝ ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, ʃaʊɾəd, "maɪ leɪɾi, maɪ lɔɹd, daʊn, kwɪkli!"

While the thud of boots and the creak of bowstrings still hung in the air, one of the soldiers, with the golden knot of an officer on his shoulder, shouted, "My Lady, my Lord, down, quickly!"

dɪspaɪɾ əɹ aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt ɑɹmz ɪleɪn dʒɹu hɝsɛlf ʌp ɹiɡəli. "ju dɛɹ tə bɹɪŋ bɛɹ stil ɪndə maɪ pɹɛzəns, tɑlænvɝ? ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn wɪl əv jə mʌkɪŋ steɪbəlz wɪð ðə minəs tʃɹupɝ fəɹ ðɪs, ɪf jə ɑɹ lʌki!"

Despite her outstretched arms Elayne drew herself up regally. "You dare to bring bare steel into my presence, Tallanvor? Gareth Bryne will have you mucking stables with the meanest trooper for this, if you are lucky!"

ðə soʊlʒɝz ɪkstʃeɪnʒd pʌzəld ɡlænsɪz, ən səm ə ðə boʊmən ənizəli hæf loʊɝd ðɛɹ baʊz. oʊnli ðən dɪɾ ɪleɪn lɛɾ əɹ ɑɹmz daʊn, əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ oʊnli hɛld əm ʌp kəz ʃi wɪʃt tə. ɡɔɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ðən fɑloʊɾ əɹ ɪɡzæmpəl. ɹænd kəd kaʊn ðə baʊz ðət hæd nɑt bɪn loʊɝd. ðə mʌsəlz ə hɪz stʌmək tɛnst əz ðoʊ ðeɪ kəd stɑp ə bɹɔdhɛd ʃæft ət twɛnti peɪsɪz.

The soldiers exchanged puzzled glances, and some of the bowmen uneasily half lowered their bows. Only then did Elayne let her arms down, as if she had only held them up because she wished to. Gawyn hesitated, then followed her example. Rand could count the bows that had not been lowered. The muscles of his stomach tensed as though they could stop a broadhead shaft at twenty paces.

ðə mæn wɪð ði ɔfəsɝz nɑt sim ðə moʊs pɝplɛkst ʌv ɔl. "maɪ leɪɾi, fɝɡɪv mi, bʌt lɔɹd ɡɑleɪdɛdʒɹəd ɹipɔɹɾəd ə dɝɾi pɛzən skʌlkɪŋ ɪn ðə ɡɑɹɾənz, ɑɹmd ən ɛndeɪnʒɝɪŋ maɪ leɪɾi ɪleɪn ən maɪ lɔɹd ɡɔɪn." hɪz aɪz wɛn tə ɹænd, ən ɪz vɔɪs fɪnd. "ɪf maɪ leɪɾi ən maɪ lɔɹd wɪl pliz tə stɛp əsaɪd, əl teɪk ðə vɪlən ɪndə kʌstəɾi. ðəɹ ɪz tu mʌtʃ ɹɪf-ɹæf ɪn ðə sɪɾi ðiz deɪz."

The man with the officer's knot seemed the most perplexed of all. "My Lady, forgive me, but Lord Galadedrid reported a dirty peasant skulking in the gardens, armed and endangering my Lady Elayne and my Lord Gawyn." His eyes went to Rand, and his voice finned. "If my Lady and my Lord will please to step aside, I will take the villain into custody. There is too much riff-raff in the city these days."

"aɪ daʊt vɛɹi mʌtʃ ɪf ɡɑləd ɹipɔɹɾəd ɛniθɪŋ ə ðə kaɪnd," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ɡɑləd dʌz nɑt laɪ."

"I doubt very much if Galad reported anything of the kind," Elayne said. "Galad does not lie."

"səmtaɪmz aɪ wɪʃ i wʊd," ɡɔɪn sɛd sɔfli, fəɹ ɹændz ɪɹ. "dʒʌst wʌns. ɪt maɪt meɪk lɪvɪŋ wɪð ɪm iziɝ."

"Sometimes I wish he would," Gawyn said softly, for Rand's ear. "Just once. It might make living with him easier."

"ðɪs mæn ɪz maɪ ɡɛst," ɪleɪn kəntɪnjud, "æn hɪɹ ʌndɝ maɪ pɹətɛkʃən. jə meɪ wɪðdʒɹɔ, tɑlænvɝ."

"This man is my guest," Elayne continued, "and here under my protection. You may withdraw, Tallanvor."

"aɪ ɹəɡɹɛt ðət wɪl nɑt bi pɑsəbəl, maɪ leɪɾi. əz maɪ leɪɾi noʊz, ðə kwin, jəɹ leɪɾi mʌðɝ, hæz ɡɪvən ɔɹɾɝz ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ɛniwʌn ɑn pæləs ɡɹaʊnz wɪθaʊɾ əɹ mædʒəstiz pɝmɪʃən, ən wɝɾ əz bɪn sɛn tə hɝ mædʒəsti ʌv ðɪs ɪntʃɹuɾɝ." ðəɹ wɑz mɔɹ ðən ə hɪn ə sæɾəsfækʃən ɪn tɑlænvɝz vɔɪs. ɹænd səspɛktəd ði ɔfəsɝ hæd hæd tə æksɛpt ʌðɝ kəmænz fɹəm ɪleɪn ðəɾ i dɪd nɑt θɪŋk pɹɑpɝ; ðɪs taɪm ðə mæn wɑz nɑɾ əbaʊt tə, nɑt wən i hæɾ ə pɝfəkt ɪkskjus.

"I regret that will not be possible, my Lady. As my Lady knows, the Queen, your lady mother, has given orders regarding anyone on Palace grounds without Her Majesty's permission, and word has been sent to Her Majesty of this intruder." There was more than a hint of satisfaction in Tallanvor's voice. Rand suspected the officer had had to accept other commands from Elayne that he did not think proper; this time the man was not about to, not when he had a perfect excuse.

ɪleɪn stɛɹd bæk ət tɑlænvɝ; fəɹ wʌns ʃi simd əɾ ə lɔs.

Elayne stared back at Tallanvor; for once she seemed at a loss.

ɹænd lʊkt ə kwɛstʃən ət ɡɔɪn, ən ɡɔɪn ʌndɝstʊd. "pɹɪzən," hi mɝmɝd. ɹændz feɪs wɛnt waɪt, ən ðə jʌŋ mæn æɾəd kwɪkli, "oʊnli fəɹ ə fju deɪz, ən jəl nɑt bi hɑɹmd. jəl bi kwɛstʃən baɪ ɡɛɹɪθ bɹaɪn, ðə kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl, pɝsənəli, bʌt jəl bi sɛt fɹi wʌns ɪts klɪɹ jə mɛnt noʊ hɑɹm." hi pɔzd, hɪɾən θɔts ɪn ɪz aɪz. "aɪ hoʊp jə wɝ tɛlɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ, ɹænd ælθɹ fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz."

Rand looked a question at Gawyn, and Gawyn understood. "Prison," he murmured. Rand's face went white, and the young man added quickly, "Only for a few days, and you will not be harmed. You'll be questioned by Gareth Bryne, the Captain-General, personally, but you will be set free once it's clear you meant no harm." He paused, hidden thoughts in his eyes. "I hope you were telling the truth, Rand al'Thor from the Two Rivers."

"ju wɪl kəndʌkt ɔl θɹi ʌv əs tə maɪ mʌðɝ," ɪleɪn ənaʊnst sʌɾənli. ə ɡɹɪn blumd ɑn ɡɔɪnz feɪs.

"You will conduct all three of us to my mother," Elayne announced suddenly. A grin bloomed on Gawyn's face.

bɪhaɪn ðə stil bɑɹz əkɹɔs ɪz feɪs, tɑlænvɝ əpɪɹd teɪkən əbæk. "maɪ leɪɾi, aɪ - "

Behind the steel bars across his face, Tallanvor appeared taken aback. "My Lady, I - "

"ɔɹ ɛls kəndʌkt ɔl θɹi ʌv əs tə ə sɛl," ɪleɪn sɛd. "wi wɪl ɹɪmeɪn təɡɛðɝ. əɹ wɪl jə ɡɪv ɔɹɾɝz fəɹ hænz tə bi leɪɾ əpɑn maɪ pɝsən?" hɝ smaɪl wɑz vɪktɔɹiəs, ən ðə weɪ tɑlænvɝ lʊkt ɝaʊn əz ɪf i ɪkspɛktəd tə faɪn hɛlp ɪn ðə tʃɹiz sɛd hi, tu, θɔt ʃi hæd wʌn.

"Or else conduct all three of us to a cell," Elayne said. "We will remain together. Or will you give orders for hands to be laid upon my person?" Her smile was victorious, and the way Tallanvor looked around as if he expected to find help in the trees said he, too, thought she had won.

wʌn wʌt? haʊ?

Won what? How?

"mʌðɝ ɪz vjuɪŋ lɑɡən," ɡɔɪn sɛd sɔfli, əz ɪf i hæd ɹɛd ɹændz θɔts, "æn ivən ɪf ʃi wɑz nɑt bɪzi, tɑlænvɝ wəd nɑt dɛɹ tʃɹup ɪndə hɝ pɹɛzəns wɪð ɪleɪn ən mi, əz ɪf wi wɝ ʌndɝ ɡɑɹd. mʌðɝ əz ə bɪɾ ʌv ə tɛmpɝ, səmtaɪmz."

"Mother is viewing Logain," Gawyn said softly, as if he had read Rand's thoughts, "and even if she was not busy, Tallanvor would not dare troop into her presence with Elayne and me, as if we were under guard. Mother has a bit of a temper, sometimes."

ɹænd ɹɪmɛmbɝd wʌt mæstɝ ɡɪl hæd sɛɾ əbaʊt kwin mɔɹɡeɪs. ə bɪɾ ʌv ə tɛmpɝ?

Rand remembered what Master Gill had said about Queen Morgase. A bit of a temper?

ənʌðɝ ɹɛd-junəfɔɹm soʊlʒɝ keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ daʊn ðə pæθ, skɪɾɪŋ tə ə hɔl tə səlut wɪð ən ɑɹm əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst. hi spoʊk sɔfli tə tɑlænvɝ, ən ɪz wɝdz bɹɔt sæɾəsfækʃən bæk tə tɑlænvɝz feɪs.

Another red-uniformed soldier came running down the path, skidding to a halt to salute with an arm across his chest. He spoke softly to Tallanvor, and his words brought satisfaction back to Tallanvor's face.

"ðə kwin, jəɹ leɪɾi mʌðɝ," tɑlænvɝ ənaʊnst, "kəmænz mi tə bɹɪŋ ði ɪntʃɹuɾɝ tə hɝ ɪmiɾiətli. ɪts ɔlsoʊ ðə kwinz kəmæn ðət maɪ leɪɾi ɪleɪn ən maɪ lɔɹd ɡɔɪn ətɛn hɝ. ɔlsoʊ ɪmiɾiətli."

"The Queen, your lady mother," Tallanvor announced, "commands me to bring the intruder to her immediately. It is also the Queen's command that my Lady Elayne and my Lord Gawyn attend her. Also immediately."

ɡɔɪn wɪnst, ən ɪleɪn swɑloʊd hɑɹd. hɝ feɪs kəmpoʊzd, ʃi stɪl bɪɡæn ɪndʌstʃɹiəsli bɹʌʃɪŋ ət ðə steɪnz ɑn əɹ dʒɹɛs. əsaɪd fɹəm dɪslɑdʒɪŋ ə fju pisəz ə bɑɹk, hɝ ɛfɝt dɪd lɪɾəl ɡʊd.

Gawyn winced, and Elayne swallowed hard. Her face composed, she still began industriously brushing at the stains on her dress. Aside from dislodging a few pieces of bark, her effort did little good.

"ɪf maɪ leɪɾi plizɪz?" tɑlænvɝ sɛd smʌɡli. "maɪ lɔɹd?"

"If my Lady pleases?" Tallanvor said smugly. "My Lord?"

ðə soʊlʒɝz fɔɹmd ɝaʊn əm ɪn ə hɑloʊ bɑks ðət stɑɹɾəd əlɔŋ ðə sleɪt pæθ wɪð tɑlænvɝ liɾɪŋ. ɡɔɪn ən ɪleɪn wɔkt ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ɹænd, boʊθ əpɪɹɪŋ lɔst ɪn ənplɛzən θɔts. ðə soʊlʒɝz hæd ʃiðd ðɛɹ sɔɹdz ən ɹɪtɝn æɹoʊz tə kwɪvɝz, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ noʊ lɛs ɑn ɡɑɹd ðən wən ðeɪ hæd hæd wɛpənz ɪn hænd. ðeɪ wɑtʃt ɹænd əz ɪf ðeɪ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪm əɾ ɛni moʊmən tə snætʃ ɪz sɔɹɾ ən tʃɹaɪ tə kʌɾ ɪz weɪ tə fɹiɾəm.

The soldiers formed around them in a hollow box that started along the slate path with Tallanvor leading. Gawyn and Elayne walked on either side of Rand, both appearing lost in unpleasant thoughts. The soldiers had sheathed their swords and returned arrows to quivers, but they were no less on guard than when they had had weapons in hand. They watched Rand as if they expected him at any moment to snatch his sword and try to cut his way to freedom.

tʃɹaɪ ɛniθɪŋ? aɪ woʊn tʃɹaɪ ɛniθɪŋ. ənnoʊɾɪst! hɑ!

Try anything? I won't try anything. Unnoticed! Hah!

wɑtʃɪŋ ðə soʊlʒɝz wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, hi sʌɾənli bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə ðə ɡɑɹɾən. wʌn θɪŋ hæd hæpən æftɝ ənʌðɝ, itʃ nu ʃɑk kʌmɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə læs hæɾ ə tʃæns tə feɪd, ən ɪz sɝaʊndɪŋz hæd bɪn ə blɝ, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə wɔl ən ɪz dɪvaʊt wɪʃ tə bi bæk ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ʌv ɪt. naʊ hi sɔ ðə ɡɹin ɡɹæs ðət hæɾ oʊnli tɪkəl ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪn bɪfɔɹ. ɡɹin! ə hʌnʒɹəd ʃeɪdz ʌv ɡɹin. tʃɹiz ən bʊʃəz ɡɹin ən θɹaɪvɪŋ, θɪk wɪð livz ən fɹut. lʌʃ vaɪnz kʌvɝɪŋ ɑɹbɝz oʊvɝ ðə pæθ. flaʊɝz ɛvɹiwɛɹ. soʊ mɛni flaʊɝz, spɹeɪɪŋ ðə ɡɑɹɾən wɪð kʌlɝ. səm i nu - bɹaɪt ɡoʊldən sʌnbɝst ən taɪni pɪŋk tælənd, kɹɪmzən stɑɹbleɪz ən pɝpəl ɛmənz ɡlɔɹi, ɹoʊzɪz ɪn ɛvɹi kʌlɝ fɹəm pjʊɹəst waɪt tə dip, dip ɹɛd - bʌɾ ʌðɝz wɝ stʃɹeɪnʒ, soʊ fænsɪfəl ɪn ʃeɪp ən hju hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðeɪ kəd bi ɹil.

Watching the soldiers watching him, he suddenly became aware of the garden. One thing had happened after another, each new shock coming before the last had a chance to fade, and his surroundings had been a blur, except for the wall and his devout wish to be back on the other side of it. Now he saw the green grass that had only tickled the back of his mind before. Green! A hundred shades of green. Trees and bushes green and thriving, thick with leaves and fruit. Lush vines covering arbors over the path. Flowers everywhere. So many flowers, spraying the garden with color. Some he knew - bright golden sunburst and tiny pink tallowend, crimson starblaze and purple Emond's Glory, roses in every color from purest white to deep, deep red - but others were strange, so fanciful in shape and hue he wondered if they could be real.

"ɪts ɡɹin," hi wɪspɝd. "ɡɹin." ðə soʊlʒɝz mʌɾɝd tə ðɛmsɛlvz; tɑlænvɝ ɡeɪv əm ə ʃɑɹp lʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ən ðeɪ fɛl saɪlənt.

"It's green," he whispered. "Green." The soldiers muttered to themselves; Tallanvor gave them a sharp look over his shoulder and they fell silent.

"ɪleɪɾəz wɝk," ɡɔɪn sɛɾ æbsənli.

"Elaida's work," Gawyn said absently.

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑt ɹaɪt," ɪleɪn sɛd. "ʃi æskt ɪf aɪ wɑntəd tə pɪk aʊt ðə wʌn fɑɹm ʃi kəd də ðə seɪm fɔɹ, waɪl ɔl ɝaʊn ɪt ðə kɹɑps stɪl feɪld, bʌɾ ɪt stɪl ɪzən ɹaɪt fəɹ əs tə hæv flaʊɝz wən ðəɹ ɑɹ pipəl u də nɑɾ əv ɪnʌf tə it." ʃi dʒɹu ə dip bɹɛθ, ən ɹifɪld əɹ sɛlf-pəzɛʃən. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ jɝsɛlf," ʃi toʊld ɹænd bɹɪskli. "spik ʌp klɪɹli wən jə ɑɹ spoʊkən tə, ən kip saɪlən ʌðɝwaɪz. ən fɑloʊ maɪ lɛd. ɔl wɪl bi wɛl."

"It is not right," Elayne said. "She asked if I wanted to pick out the one farm she could do the same for, while all around it the crops still failed, but it still isn't right for us to have flowers when there are people who do not have enough to eat." She drew a deep breath, and refilled her self-possession. "Remember yourself," she told Rand briskly. "Speak up clearly when you are spoken to, and keep silent otherwise. And follow my lead. All will be well."

ɹænd wɪʃt i kəd ʃɛɹ əɹ kɑnfəɾəns. ɪt wʊɾə hɛlpt ɪf ɡɔɪn hæd sim tə hæv ɪɾ əz wɛl. əz tɑlænvɝ lɛɾ əm ɪndə ðə pæləs, hi lʊk bæk ət ðə ɡɑɹɾən, əɾ ɔl ðə ɡɹin stʃɹikt wɪð blɑsəmz, kʌlɝz ɹɔt fəɹ ə kwin baɪ ən ɛɛs sədaɪz hænd. hi wɑz ɪn dip wɔɾɝ, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bæŋk ɪn saɪt.

Rand wished he could share her confidence. It would have helped if Gawyn had seemed to have it as well. As Tallanvor led them into the Palace, he looked back at the garden, at all the green streaked with blossoms, colors wrought for a Queen by an Aes Sedai's hand. He was in deep water, and there was no bank in sight.

pæləs sɝvəns fɪl ðə hɔlz, ɪn ɹɛd lɪvɝiz wɪð kɑlɝz ən kʌfs ʌv waɪt, ðə waɪt laɪən ɑn ðə lɛf bɹɛst ə ðɛɹ tunɪks, skɝiɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪntɛn ɑn tæsks ðət wɝ nɑt ɹɛɾəli əpɛɹənt. wən ðə soʊlʒɝz tʃɹup baɪ wɪð ɪleɪn ən ɡɔɪn, ən ɹænd, ɪn ðɛɹ mɪdst, ðeɪ stɑp dɛɾ ɪn ðɛɹ tʃɹæks tə stɛɹ oʊpənməðd.

Palace servants filled the halls, in red liveries with collars and cuffs of white, the White Lion on the left breast of their tunics, scurrying about intent on tasks that were not readily apparent. When the soldiers trooped by with Elayne and Gawyn, and Rand, in their midst, they stopped dead in their tracks to stare openmouthed.

θɹu ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɔl ðə kɑnstɝneɪʃən ə ɡɹeɪ-stʃɹaɪp tɑmkæt wɑndɝɾ ʌnkənsɝnədli daʊn ðə hɔl, wivɪŋ bɪtwin ðə ɡɑəlɪŋ sɝvəns. sʌɾənli ðə kæt stʃɹʌk ɹænd əz ɑd. hi hæd bɪn ɪn bɛɹlən lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə noʊ ðəɾ ivən ðə minəst ʃɑp hæd kæts lɝkɪŋ ɪn ɛvɹi kɔɹnɝ. sɪns ɛntɝɪŋ ðə pæləs, ðə tɑm wɑz ði oʊnli kæɾ i hæd sin.

Through the middle of all the consternation a gray-striped tomcat wandered unconcernedly down the hall, weaving between the goggling servants. Suddenly the cat struck Rand as odd. He had been in Baerlon long enough to know that even the meanest shop had cats lurking in every corner. Since entering the Palace, the tom was the only cat he had seen.

"ju doʊn əv ɹæts?" hi sɛɾ ɪn dɪsbɪlif. ɛvɹi pleɪs hæd ɹæts.

"You don't have rats?" he said in disbelief. Every place had rats.

"ɪleɪɾə dʌzn laɪk ɹæts," ɡɔɪn mʌɾɝd veɪɡli. hi wɑz fɹaʊnɪŋ wɝidli daʊn ðə hɔl, əpɛɹənli ɔlɹɛɾi siɪŋ ðə kʌmɪŋ miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə kwin. "wi nɛvɝ əv ɹæts."

"Elaida doesn't like rats," Gawyn muttered vaguely. He was frowning worriedly down the hall, apparently already seeing the coming meeting with the Queen. "We never have rats."

"boʊθ ə jə bi kwaɪət." ɪleɪnz vɔɪs wɑz ʃɑɹp, bʌɾ əz æbsən əz əɹ bɹʌðɝz. "aɪ æm tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə θɪŋk."

"Both of you be quiet." Elayne's voice was sharp, but as absent as her brother's. "I am trying to think."

ɹænd wɑtʃt ðə kæɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ əntɪl ðə ɡɑɹdz tʊk ɪm ɹaʊn ə kɔɹnɝ, haɪɾɪŋ ðə tɑm fɹəm saɪt. ə lɑɾ ə kæts wʊɾə meɪɾ ɪm fil bɛɾɝ; ɪt wʊɾə bɪn naɪs ɪf ðəɹ wɑz wʌn θɪŋ nɔɹməl əbaʊt ðə pæləs, ivən ɪf ɪt wɑz ɹæts.

Rand watched the cat over his shoulder until the guards took him round a corner, hiding the tom from sight. A lot of cats would have made him feel better; it would have been nice if there was one thing normal about the Palace, even if it was rats.

ðə pæθ tɑlænvɝ tʊk tɝn soʊ mɛni taɪmz ðət ɹænd lɔst ɪz sɛns ə dɝɛkʃən. faɪnəli ðə jʌŋ ɔfəsɝ stɑp bɪfɔɹ tɔl dʌbəl dɔɹz ə dɑɹk wʊd wɪð ə ɹɪtʃ ɡloʊ, nɑt soʊ ɡɹæn əz səm ðeɪ hæd pæst, bʌt stɪl kɑɹvd ɔl oʊvɝ wɪð ɹoʊz ə laɪənz, faɪnli ɹɔɾ ɪn dɪteɪl. ə lɪvɹid sɝvən stʊd tə iðɝ saɪd.

The path Tallanvor took turned so many times that Rand lost his sense of direction. Finally the young officer stopped before tall double doors of dark wood with a rich glow, not so grand as some they had passed, but still carved all over with rows of lions, finely wrought in detail. A liveried servant stood to either side.

"æt list ɪɾ ɪzən ðə ɡɹæn hɔl." ɡɔɪn læft ənstɛɾəli. "aɪ nɛvɝ hɝd ðət mʌðɝ kəmændəɾ ɛniwʌnz hɛd kʌɾ ɔf fɹəm hɪɹ." hi saʊndəɾ əz ɪf i θɔt ʃi maɪt sɛɾ ə pɹɛsɪɾənt.

"At least it isn't the Grand Hall." Gawyn laughed unsteadily. "I never heard that Mother commanded anyone's head cut off from here." He sounded as if he thought she might set a precedent.

tɑlænvɝ ɹitʃt fəɹ ɹændz sɔɹd, bʌɾ ɪleɪn muv tə kʌɾ ɪm ɔf. "hi ɪz maɪ ɡɛst, ən baɪ kʌstəm ən lɔ, ɡɛsts ə ðə ɹɔɪəl fæmli meɪ ɡoʊ ɑɹmd ivən ɪn mʌðɝz pɹɛzəns. əɹ wɪl jə dɪnaɪ maɪ wɝd ðət hiz maɪ ɡɛst?"

Tallanvor reached for Rand's sword, but Elayne moved to cut him off. "He is my guest, and by custom and law, guests of the royal family may go armed even in Mother's presence. Or will you deny my word that he is my guest?"

tɑlænvɝ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, lɑkɪŋ aɪz wɪð hɝ, ðən nɑɾəd. "vɛɹi wɛl, maɪ leɪɾi." ʃi smaɪld ət ɹænd əz tɑlænvɝ stɛp bæk, bʌɾ ɪt læstəɾ oʊnli ə moʊmənt. "fɝst ɹæŋk tə əkʌmpəni mi," tɑlænvɝ kəmændəd. "ənaʊns ðə leɪɾi ɪleɪn ən ðə lɔɹd ɡɔɪn tə hɝ mædʒəsti," hi toʊl ðə dɔɹkipɝz. "ɔlsoʊ ɡɑɹdzmæn-lutɛnən tɑlænvɝ, əɾ əɹ mædʒəstiz kəmænd, wɪð ði ɪntʃɹuɾɝ ʌndɝ ɡɑɹd."

Tallanvor hesitated, locking eyes with her, then nodded. "Very well, my Lady." She smiled at Rand as Tallanvor stepped back, but it lasted only a moment. "First rank to accompany me," Tallanvor commanded. "Announce the Lady Elayne and the Lord Gawyn to Her Majesty," he told the doorkeepers. "Also Guardsman-Lieutenant Tallanvor, at Her Majesty's command, with the intruder under guard."

ɪleɪn skaʊld ət tɑlænvɝ, bʌt ðə dɔɹz wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi swɪŋɪŋ oʊpən. ə sɑnɝəs vɔɪs saʊndəd, ənaʊnsɪŋ ðoʊz u keɪm.

Elayne scowled at Tallanvor, but the doors were already swinging open. A sonorous voice sounded, announcing those who came.

ɡɹænli ɪleɪn swɛp θɹu ðə dɔɹz, spɔɪlɪŋ əɹ ɹiɡəl ɛntʃɹəns oʊnli ə lɪɾəl baɪ moʊʃənɪŋ fəɹ ɹænd tə kip kloʊs bɪhaɪn hɝ. ɡɔɪn skwɛɹɾ ɪz ʃoʊldɝz ən stʃɹoʊɾ ɪn flæŋkɪŋ hɝ, wʌn mɛʒɝd peɪs tə hɝ ɹɪɹ. ɹænd fɑloʊd, ənsɝteɪnli kipɪŋ lɛvəl wɪð ɡɔɪn ɑn əɹ ʌðɝ saɪd. tɑlænvɝ steɪd kloʊs tə ɹænd, ən tɛn soʊlʒɝz keɪm wɪð hɪm. ðə dɔɹz kloʊz saɪlənli bɪhaɪn ðɛm.

Grandly Elayne swept through the doors, spoiling her regal entrance only a little by motioning for Rand to keep close behind her. Gawyn squared his shoulders and strode in flanking her, one measured pace to her rear. Rand followed, uncertainly keeping level with Gawyn on her other side. Tallanvor stayed close to Rand, and ten soldiers came with him. The doors closed silently behind them.

sʌɾənli ɪleɪn dʒɹɑpt ɪndə ə dip kɝtsi, saɪməlteɪniəsli boʊɪŋ fɹəm ðə weɪst, ən steɪd ðɛɹ, hoʊldɪŋ əɹ skɝt waɪd. ɹænd ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ðən heɪstəli ɛmjəleɪɾɪd ɡɔɪn ən ði ʌðɝ mɛn, ʃɪftɪŋ ɔkwɝdli əntɪl i hæɾ ɪt ɹaɪt. daʊn ɑn ɪz ɹaɪt ni, hɛd baʊd, bɛndɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə pɹɛs ðə nʌkəlz ə hɪz ɹaɪt hæn əɡɛns ðə mɑɹbəl taɪlz, hɪz lɛf hæn ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn ði ɛn ə hɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. ɡɔɪn, wɪθaʊɾ ə sɔɹd, pʊɾ ɪz hæn ɑn ɪz dæɡɝ ðə seɪm weɪ.

Suddenly Elayne dropped into a deep curtsy, simultaneously bowing from the waist, and stayed there, holding her skirt wide. Rand gave a start, then hastily emulated Gawyn and the other men, shifting awkwardly until he had it right. Down on his right knee, head bowed, bending forward to press the knuckles of his right hand against the marble tiles, his left hand resting on the end of his sword hilt. Gawyn, without a sword, put his hand on his dagger the same way.

ɹænd wɑz dʒʌs kənɡɹætʃəleɪɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɑn ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪt ɹaɪt wən i noʊɾəst tɑlænvɝ, hɪz hɛd stɪl bɛnt, ɡlɛɹɪŋ saɪdweɪz əɾ ɪm fɹəm bɪhaɪn ɪz feɪs-ɡɑɹd. wɑz aɪ səpoʊz tə də sʌmθɪŋ ɛls? hi wɑz sʌɾənli æŋɡɹi ðət tɑlænvɝ ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪm tə noʊ wʌt tə də wən noʊ wʌn hæd toʊl hɪm. ən æŋɡɹi oʊvɝ biɪŋ əfɹeɪɾ ə ðə ɡɑɹdz. hi hæd dʌn nʌθɪŋ tə bi fɪɹfəl fɔɹ. hi nu hɪz fɪɹ wɑz nɑt tɑlænvɝz fɔlt, bʌɾ i wɑz æŋɡɹi əɾ ɪm ɛniweɪ.

Rand was just congratulating himself on getting it right when he noticed Tallanvor, his head still bent, glaring sideways at him from behind his face-guard. Was I supposed to do something else? He was suddenly angry that Tallanvor expected him to know what to do when no one had told him. And angry over being afraid of the guards. He had done nothing to be fearful for. He knew his fear was not Tallanvor's fault, but he was angry at him anyway.

ɛvɹiwʌn hɛl ðɛɹ pəzɪʃənz, fɹoʊzən əz ɪf weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ðə spɹɪŋ θɔ. hi dɪd nɑt noʊ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ weɪɾɪŋ fɔɹ, bʌɾ i tʊk ði ɑpɝtunəɾi tə stʌɾi ðə pleɪs tə wɪtʃ i hæd bɪn bɹɔt. hi kɛpt ɪz hɛd daʊn, dʒʌs tɝnɪŋ ɪɾ ɪnʌf tə si. tɑlænvɝz skaʊl dipənd, bʌɾ i ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪt.

Everyone held their positions, frozen as if waiting for the spring thaw. He did not know what they were waiting for, but he took the opportunity to study the place to which he had been brought. He kept his head down, just turning it enough to see. Tallanvor's scowl deepened, but he ignored it.

ðə skwɛɹ tʃeɪmbɝ wɑz əbaʊt ðə saɪz ə ðə kɑmən ɹum ət ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ, ɪts wɔlz pɹɪzɛntɪŋ hʌntɪŋ sinz kɑɹvd ɪn ɹɪlif ɪn stoʊn ə ðə pjʊɹəst waɪt. ðə tæpəstʃɹiz bɪtwin ðə kɑɹvɪŋz wɝ dʒɛntəl ɪmədʒəz ə bɹaɪt flaʊɝz ən bɹɪljənli pluməɡd hʌmɪŋbɝdz, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə tu ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə ɹum, wɛɹ ðə waɪt laɪən ʌv ændɝ stʊd tɔlɝ ðən ə mæn ɑn skɑɹlət filz. ðoʊz tu hæŋʒɪŋz flæŋkt ə deɪz, ən ɑn ðə deɪz ə kɑɹvd ən ɡɪldɪd θɹoʊn wɛɹ sæt ðə kwin.
