"mɔɪɹeɪn dɪdn lʊk əɾ ɛniθɪŋ ɛni mɔɹ ðən læn dɪd. ʃi lɛɾ əs bæk ən fɔɹθ θɹu ɔl ðoʊz stʃɹits soʊ mɛni taɪmz, laɪk ə dɔɡ hʌntɪŋ ə sɛnt, ðəɾ aɪ θɔt jə kʊdn bi hɪɹ. ðɛn, ɔl ʌv ə sʌɾən, ʃi tʊk ɔf daʊn ə stʃɹit, ən ðə nɛks θɪŋ aɪ nu wi wɝ hændɪŋ ðə hɔɹsəz tə ðə steɪbəlmən ən mɑɹtʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə kɪtʃən. ʃi nɛvɝ ivən æskt ɪf jə wɝ hɪɹ. dʒʌs toʊld ə wʊmən u wɑz mɪksɪŋ bæɾɝ tə ɡoʊ tɛl ɹænd ælθɹ ən mæt kɔθən ðət sʌmwʌn wɑntəd tə si ðɛm. ən ðəɹ jə wɝ" - ʃi ɡɹɪnd - "laɪk ə bɔl pɑpɪŋ ɪndə ðə ɡlimənz hæn aʊɾ ə noʊwɛɹ."

Egwene gave him a look, but she removed her hand from the sword and took up where Perrin had left off. "Moiraine didn't look at anything any more than Lan did. She led us back and forth through all those streets so many times, like a dog hunting a scent, that I thought you couldn't be here. Then, all of a sudden, she took off down a street, and the next thing I knew we were handing the horses to the stablemen and marching into the kitchen. She never even asked if you were here. Just told a woman who was mixing batter to go tell Rand al'Thor and Mat Cauthon that someone wanted to see them. And there you were" - she grinned - "like a ball popping into the gleeman's hand out of nowhere."

"wɛɹ ɪz ðə ɡlimən?" pɛɹɪn æskt. "ɪz i wɪð ju?"

"Where is the gleeman?" Perrin asked. "Is he with you?"

ɹændz stʌmək lɝtʃt ən ðə ɡʊd filɪŋ ə hævɪŋ fɹɛnz ɝaʊn ɪm dɪmd. "tɑmz dɛd. aɪ θɪŋk hiz dɛd. ðəɹ wɑz ə feɪd. . . ." hi kəd nɑt seɪ ɛni mɔɹ. nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ.

Rand's stomach lurched and the good feeling of having friends around him dimmed. "Thom's dead. I think he's dead. There was a Fade. . . ." He could not say any more. Nynaeve shook her head, muttering under her breath.

ðə saɪləns θɪkən ɝaʊn ðɛm, staɪflɪŋ ðə lɪɾəl tʃʌkəlz, flæɾənɪŋ ðə dʒɔɪ, əntɪl ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə hɛɾ ə ðə stɛɹz.

The silence thickened around them, stifling the little chuckles, flattening the joy, until they reached the head of the stairs.

"mæts nɑt sɪk, ɪɡzækli," hi sɛd ðɛn. "ɪts. . . . jəl si." hi flʌŋ oʊpən ðə dɔɹ tə ðə ɹum i ʃɛɹd wɪð mæt. "lʊk huz hɪɹ, mæt."

"Mat's not sick, exactly," he said then. "It's. . . . You'll see." He flung open the door to the room he shared with Mat. "Look who's here, Mat."

mæt wɑz stɪl kɝld ʌp ɪn ə bɔl ɑn ðə bɛd, dʒʌst əz ɹænd hæd lɛf hɪm. hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛd tə stɛɹ ət ðɛm. "haʊ dʒju noʊ ðəɹ ɹɪli hu ðeɪ lʊk laɪk?" hi sɛd hɔɹsli. hɪz feɪs wɑz flʌʃt, ðə skɪn taɪɾ ən slɪk wɪð swɛt. "haʊ də aɪ noʊ jəɹ u jə lʊk laɪk?"

Mat was still curled up in a ball on the bed, just as Rand had left him. He raised his head to stare at them. "How do you know they're really who they look like?" he said hoarsely. His face was flushed, the skin tight and slick with sweat. "How do I know you're who you look like?"

"nɑt sɪk?" nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ɹænd ə dɪsdeɪnfəl lʊk əz ʃi pʊʃt pæs hɪm, ɔlɹɛɾi ənslɪŋɪŋ əɹ bæɡ fɹəm əɹ ʃoʊldɝ.

"Not sick?" Nynaeve gave Rand a disdainful look as she pushed past him, already unslinging her bag from her shoulder.

"ɛvɹibɑɾi tʃeɪnʒəz," mæt ɹæspt. "haʊ kən aɪ bi ʃʊɹ? pɛɹɪn? ɪz ðət ju? juv tʃeɪnʒd, hævən ju?" hɪz læf saʊndəd mɔɹ laɪk ə kɑf. "oʊ, jɛs, juv tʃeɪnʒd."

"Everybody changes," Mat rasped. "How can I be sure? Perrin? Is that you? You've changed, haven't you?" His laugh sounded more like a cough. "Oh, yes, you've changed."

tə ɹændz sɝpɹaɪz pɛɹɪn dʒɹɑpt ɑntu ði ɛdʒ ə ði ʌðɝ bɛd wɪð ɪz hɛɾ ɪn hænz, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə flɔɹ. mæts hækɪŋ læftɝ sim tə pɪɹs hɪm.

To Rand's surprise Perrin dropped onto the edge of the other bed with his head in hands, staring at the floor. Mat's hacking laughter seemed to pierce him.

nɪneɪiv nɛl bɪsaɪd mæts bɛɾ ən pʊɾ ə hæn tə hɪz feɪs, pʊʃɪŋ ʌp ɪz hɛdklɔθ. hi dʒɝk bæk fɹəm əɹ wɪð ə skɔɹnfəl lʊk. hɪz aɪz wɝ bɹaɪɾ ən ɡleɪzd. "jɔɹ bɝnɪŋ," ʃi sɛd, "bʌt jə ʃəd nɑt bi swɛɾɪŋ wɪð ðɪs mʌtʃ fivɝ." ʃi kəd nɑt kip ðə wɝi aʊɾ ə hɝ vɔɪs. "ɹænd, jə ən pɛɹɪn fɛtʃ səm klin klɔθs ən əz mʌtʃ kul wɔɾɝ əz jə kən kæɹi. əl bɹɪŋ jəɹ tɛmpɹətʃɝ daʊn fɝst, mæt, ən - "

Nynaeve knelt beside Mat's bed and put a hand to his face, pushing up his headcloth. He jerked back from her with a scornful look. His eyes were bright and glazed. "You're burning," she said, "but you should not be sweating with this much fever." She could not keep the worry out of her voice. "Rand, you and Perrin fetch some clean cloths and as much cool water as you can carry. I'll bring your temperature down first, Mat, and - "

"pɹɪɾi nɪneɪiv," mæt spæt. "eɪ wɪzdəm ɪzən səpoʊz tə θɪŋk ə hɝsɛlf əz ə wʊmən, ɪz ʃi? nɑɾ ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən. bʌt jə du, doʊn ju? naʊ. jə kæn meɪk jɝsɛlf fɝɡɛt ðət jəɹ ə pɹɪɾi wʊmən, naʊ, ən ɪt fɹaɪɾənz ju. ɛvɹibɑɾi tʃeɪnʒəz." nɪneɪivz feɪs peɪld əz i spoʊk - wɛðɝ wɪð æŋɡɝ əɹ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, ɹænd kəd nɑt tɛl. mæt ɡeɪv ə slaɪ læf, ən ɪz fivɝɪʃ aɪz slɪd tə ɛɡwin. "pɹɪɾi ɛɡwin," hi kɹoʊkt. "pɹɪɾi əz nɪneɪiv. ən jə ʃɛɹ ʌðɝ θɪŋz naʊ, doʊn ju? ʌðɝ dʒɹimz. wʌt dʒju dʒɹim əbaʊt naʊ?" ɛɡwin tʊk ə stɛp bæk fɹəm ðə bɛd.

"Pretty Nynaeve," Mat spat. "A Wisdom isn't supposed to think of herself as a woman, is she? Not a pretty woman. But you do, don't you? Now. You can't make yourself forget that you're a pretty woman, now, and it frightens you. Everybody changes." Nynaeve's face paled as he spoke - whether with anger or something else, Rand could not tell. Mat gave a sly laugh, and his feverish eyes slid to Egwene. "Pretty Egwene," he croaked. "Pretty as Nynaeve. And you share other things now, don't you? Other dreams. What do you dream about now?" Egwene took a step back from the bed.

"wi ɑɹ seɪf fɹəm ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪz fəɹ ðə taɪm biɪŋ," mɔɪɹeɪn ənaʊnst əz ʃi wɔkt ɪndə ðə ɹum wɪð læn əɾ əɹ hilz. hɝ aɪz fɛl ɑn mæt əz ʃi stɛp θɹu ðə dɔɹweɪ, ən ʃi hɪst əz ɪf ʃi hæd tʌtʃt ə hɑt stoʊv. "ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm hɪm!"

"We are safe from the Dark One's eyes for the time being," Moiraine announced as she walked into the room with Lan at her heels. Her eyes fell on Mat as she stepped through the doorway, and she hissed as if she had touched a hot stove. "Get away from him!"

nɪneɪiv dɪd nɑt muv ɪksɛp fəɹ tɝnɪŋ tə stɛɹ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn sɝpɹaɪz. ɪn tu kwɪk stɛps mɔɪɹeɪn siz ðə wɪzdəm baɪ ðə ʃoʊldɝz, hɔlɪŋ əɹ əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ laɪk ə sæk ʌv ɡɹeɪn. nɪneɪiv stʃɹʌɡəld ən pɹətɛstəd, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd nɑt ɹilis əɹ əntɪl ʃi wɑz wɛl əweɪ fɹəm ðə bɛd. ðə wɪzdəm kəntɪnjuɾ əɹ pɹoʊɾɛsts əz ʃi ɡɑt tə hɝ fit, æŋɡɹəli stʃɹeɪɾənɪŋ əɹ kloʊðz, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn ɪɡnɔɹɾ əɹ kəmplitli. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑtʃt mæt tə ði ɪkskluʒən ʌv ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɛls, aɪɪŋ ɪm ðə weɪ ʃi wəɾ ə vaɪpɝ.

Nynaeve did not move except for turning to stare at the Aes Sedai in surprise. In two quick steps Moiraine seized the Wisdom by the shoulders, hauling her across the floor like a sack of grain. Nynaeve struggled and protested, but Moiraine did not release her until she was well away from the bed. The Wisdom continued her protests as she got to her feet, angrily straightening her clothes, but Moiraine ignored her completely. The Aes Sedai watched Mat to the exclusion of everything else, eyeing him the way she would a viper.

"ɔl ə jə steɪ əweɪ fɹəm hɪm," ʃi sɛd. "æn bi kwaɪət."

"All of you stay away from him," she said. "And be quiet."

mæt stɛɹd bæk əz ɪntɛnli əz ʃi. hi bɛɹɾ ɪz tiθ ɪn ə saɪlənt, snɑɹlɪŋ ɹɪktəs, ən pʊl hɪmsɛlf ɪndə ən ɛvɝ taɪɾɝ nɑt, bʌɾ i nɛvɝ tʊk ɪz aɪz fɹəm hɝz. sloʊli ʃi pʊt wʌn hæn ɑn hɪm, laɪtli, ɑn ə ni dʒɹɔn ʌp tə hɪz tʃɛst. ə kənvʌlʃən ʃʊk ɪm əɾ əɹ tʌtʃ, ə ʃʌɾɝ ə ɹɪvʌlʃən spæzəmɪŋ θɹu hɪz ɪntaɪɝ bɑɾi, ən əbɹʌpli hi pʊld wʌn hæn aʊt, slæʃɪŋ əɾ əɹ feɪs wɪð ðə ɹubi-hɪltɪd dæɡɝ.

Mat stared back as intently as she. He bared his teeth in a silent, snarling rictus, and pulled himself into an ever tighter knot, but he never took his eyes from hers. Slowly she put one hand on him, lightly, on a knee drawn up to his chest. A convulsion shook him at her touch, a shudder of revulsion spasming through his entire body, and abruptly he pulled one hand out, slashing at her face with the ruby-hilted dagger.

wʌn mɪnət læn wɑz ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, ðə nɛkst i wɑz ət ðə bɛdsaɪd, əz ɪf i hæd nɑt bɑðɝd wɪð ði ɪntɝvinɪŋ speɪs. hɪz hæn kɑt mæts ɹɪst, stɑpɪŋ ðə slæʃ əz ɪf ɪt hæd stʃɹʌk stoʊn. stɪl mæt hɛl hɪmsɛlf ɪn ðət taɪt bɔl. oʊnli ðə hænd wɪð ðə dæɡɝ tʃɹaɪd tə muv, stʃɹeɪnɪŋ əɡɛns ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɪmplækəbəl ɡɹɪp. mæts aɪz nɛvɝ lɛf mɔɪɹeɪn, ən ðeɪ bɝnd wɪð heɪt.

One minute Lan was in the doorway, the next he was at the bedside, as if he had not bothered with the intervening space. His hand caught Mat's wrist, stopping the slash as if it had struck stone. Still Mat held himself in that tight ball. Only the hand with the dagger tried to move, straining against the Warder's implacable grip. Mat's eyes never left Moiraine, and they burned with hate.

mɔɪɹeɪn ɔlsoʊ dɪd nɑt muv. ʃi dɪd nɑt flɪntʃ fɹəm ðə bleɪɾ oʊnli ɪntʃəz fɹəm əɹ feɪs, əz ʃi hæd nɑt wən i fɝst stʃɹʌk. "haʊ dɪɾ i kʌm baɪ ðɪs?" ʃi æskt ɪn ə stil vɔɪs. "aɪ æskt ɪf mɔɹɾɪθ hæd ɡɪvən jə ɛniθɪŋ. aɪ æskt, ən aɪ wɔɹn ju, ən jə sɛɾ i hæd nɑt."

Moiraine also did not move. She did not flinch from the blade only inches from her face, as she had not when he first struck. "How did he come by this?" she asked in a steel voice. "I asked if Mordeth had given you anything. I asked, and I warned you, and you said he had not."

"hi dɪdnt," ɹænd sɛd. "hi. . . . mæt tʊk ɪt fɹəm ðə tʃɹɛʒɝ ɹummɔɪɹeɪn lʊkt ət hɪm, hɝ aɪz simɪŋ tə bɝn əz mʌtʃ əz mæts. hi ɔlmoʊst stɛp bæk bɪfɔɹ ʃi tɝn əweɪ əɡɛn, bæk tə ðə bɛd. "aɪ dɪdnt noʊ əntɪl æftɝ wi wɝ sɛpɝeɪɾəd. aɪ dɪdnt noʊ."

"He didn't," Rand said. "He. . . . Mat took it from the treasure room."Moiraine looked at him, her eyes seeming to burn as much as Mat's. He almost stepped back before she turned away again, back to the bed. "I didn't know until after we were separated. I didn't know."

"ju dɪd nɑt noʊ." mɔɪɹeɪn stʌɾid mæt. hi stɪl leɪ wɪð ɪz niz pʊld ʌp tə hɪz tʃɛst, stɪl snɑɹəl saʊnləsli ət hɝ, ən ɪz hæn jɛt fɔt læn tə ɹitʃ əɹ wɪð ðə dæɡɝ. "ɪɾ ɪz ə wʌndɝ jə ɡɑt ðɪs fɑɹ, kæɹiɪŋ ðɪs. aɪ fɛl ði ivəl ʌv ɪt wən aɪ leɪɾ aɪz ɑn hɪm, ðə tʌtʃ ə mɑʃəɾɝ, bʌɾ ə feɪd kəd sɛns ɪt fəɹ maɪlz. ivən ðoʊ hi wəd nɑt noʊ ɪɡzækli wɛɹ, hi wəd noʊ ɪt wɑz nɪɹ, ən mɑʃəɾɝ wəd dʒɹɔ hɪz spɪɹət waɪl ɪz boʊnz ɹɪmɛmbɝd ðət ðɪs seɪm ivəl swɑloʊɾ ən ɑɹmi - dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz, feɪdz, tʃɹɑləks, ən ɔl. səm dɑɹkfɹɛnz kəd pɹɑbli fil ɪt, tu. ðoʊz u hæv tʃɹuli ɡɪvən əweɪ ðɛɹ soʊlz. ðəɹ kəd nɑt hɛlp bʌt bi ðoʊz u wəd wʌndɝ ət sʌɾənli filɪŋ ðɪs, əz ɪf ðə vɛɹi ɛɹ ɝaʊn əm ɪtʃt. ðeɪ wəd bi kəmpɛl tə sik ɪt. ɪt ʃʊɾə dʒɹɔn əm tə ɪɾ əz ə mæɡnət dʒɹɔz aɪɝn faɪlɪŋz."

"You did not know." Moiraine studied Mat. He still lay with his knees pulled up to his chest, still snarled soundlessly at her, and his hand yet fought Lan to reach her with the dagger. "It is a wonder you got this far, carrying this. I felt the evil of it when I laid eyes on him, the touch of Mashadar, but a Fade could sense it for miles. Even though he would not know exactly where, he would know it was near, and Mashadar would draw his spirit while his bones remembered that this same evil swallowed an army - Dreadlords, Fades, Trollocs, and all. Some Darkfriends could probably feel it, too. Those who have truly given away their souls. There could not help but be those who would wonder at suddenly feeling this, as if the very air around them itched. They would be compelled to seek it. It should have drawn them to it as a magnet draws iron filings."

"ðɛɹ wɝ dɑɹkfɹɛnz," ɹænd sɛd, "mɔɹ ðən wʌns, bʌt wi ɡɑɾ əweɪ fɹəm ðɛm. ən ə feɪd, ðə naɪt bɪfɔɹ wi ɹitʃt keɪɛmlɪn, bʌɾ i nɛvɝ sɔ ʌs." hi klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ ɹumɝz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋz ɪn ðə naɪɾ aʊtsaɪd ðə sɪɾi. ɪt kəd bi tʃɹɑləks."

"There were Darkfriends," Rand said, "more than once, but we got away from them. And a Fade, the night before we reached Caemlyn, but he never saw us." He cleared his throat. "There are rumors of strange things in the night outside the city. It could be Trollocs."

"oʊ, ɪts tʃɹɑləks, ʃifɝɾɝ," læn sɛd ɹaɪli. "ænd wɛɹ tʃɹɑləks ɑɹ, ðəɹ ɑɹ feɪdz." tɛndənz stʊɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz hæn fɹəm ði ɛfɝɾ ə hoʊldɪŋ mæts ɹɪst, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz noʊ stʃɹeɪn ɪn ɪz vɔɪs. "ðeɪv tʃɹaɪd tə haɪd ðɛɹ pæsədʒ, bʌɾ aɪ hæv sin saɪn fəɹ tu deɪz. ən hɝd fɑɹmɝz ən vɪlɪdʒɝz mʌɾɝ əbaʊt θɪŋz ɪn ðə naɪt. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl mænədʒ tə stʃɹaɪk ɪndə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ənsin, sʌmhaʊ, bʌɾ ɛvɹi deɪ ðeɪ kʌm kloʊsɝ tə ðoʊz u kən sɛn soʊlʒɝz tə hʌn əm daʊn. ivən soʊ, ðeɪ woʊn stɑp naʊ, ʃifɝɾɝ."

"Oh, it's Trollocs, sheepherder," Lan said wryly. "And where Trollocs are, there are Fades." Tendons stood out on the back of his hand from the effort of holding Mat's wrist, but there was no strain in his voice. "They've tried to hide their passage, but I have seen sign for two days. And heard farmers and villagers mutter about things in the night. The Myrddraal managed to strike into the Two Rivers unseen, somehow, but every day they come closer to those who can send soldiers to hunt them down. Even so, they won't stop now, sheepherder."

"bʌt wɝ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn," ɛɡwin sɛd. "ðeɪ kænt ɡɛt tə əs əz lɔŋ əz - "

"But we're in Caemlyn," Egwene said. "They can't get to us as long as - "

"ðeɪ kænt?" ðə wɔɹɾɝ kʌɾ əɹ ɔf. "ðə feɪdz ɑɹ bɪldɪŋ ðɛɹ nʌmbɝz ɪn ðə kʌntʃɹisaɪd. ðæts pleɪn ɪnʌf fɹəm ðə saɪn, ɪf jə noʊ wʌt tə lʊk fɔɹ. ɔlɹɛɾi ðəɹ ɑɹ mɔɹ tʃɹɑləks ðən ðeɪ nid dʒʌs tə wɑtʃ ɔl ðə weɪz aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi, ə dʌzən fɪsts, ət list. ðəɹ kən oʊnli bi wʌn ɹizən; wən ðə feɪdz əv ɪnʌf nʌmbɝz, ðəl kʌm ɪndə ðə sɪɾi æftɝ ju. ðəɾ æk meɪ sɛn hæf ði ɑɹmiz ə ðə saʊθ mɑɹtʃɪŋ tə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, bʌt ði ɛvəɾəns ɪz ðət ðəɹ wɪlɪŋ tə teɪk ðət ɹɪsk. jə θɹi hæv ɪskeɪpt əm tu lɔŋ. ɪt lʊks əz ɪf juv bɹɔɾ ə nu tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹ tə keɪɛmlɪn, ʃifɝɾɝ."

"They can't?" the Warder cut her off. "The Fades are building their numbers in the countryside. That's plain enough from the sign, if you know what to look for. Already there are more Trollocs than they need just to watch all the ways out of the city, a dozen fists, at least. There can only be one reason; when the Fades have enough numbers, they will come into the city after you. That act may send half the armies of the south marching to the Borderlands, but the evidence is that they're willing to take that risk. You three have escaped them too long. It looks as if you've brought a new Trolloc War to Caemlyn, sheepherder."

ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ə ɡæspɪŋ sɑb, ən pɛɹɪn ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əz ðoʊ tə dɪnaɪ ɪt. ɹænd fɛlt ə sɪknəs ɪn ɪz stʌmək ət ðə θɔɾ ə tʃɹɑləks ɪn ðə stʃɹits ə keɪɛmlɪn. ɔl ðoʊz pipəl ət wʌn ənʌðɝz θɹoʊts, nɛvɝ ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðə ɹil θɹɛt weɪɾɪŋ tə kʌm oʊvɝ ðə wɔlz. wʌt wəd ðeɪ də wən ðeɪ sʌɾənli faʊn tʃɹɑləks ən feɪdz ɪn ðɛɹ mɪdst, kɪlɪŋ ðɛm? hi kəd si ðə taʊɝz bɝnɪŋ, fleɪmz bɹeɪkɪŋ θɹu ðə doʊmz, tʃɹɑləks pɪlɪdʒɪŋ θɹu ðə kɝvɪŋ stʃɹits ən vɪstəz ə ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi. ðə pæləs ɪtsɛlf ɪn fleɪmz. ɪleɪn, ən ɡɔɪn, ən mɔɹɡeɪs . . . dɛd.

Egwene gave a gasping sob, and Perrin shook his head as though to deny it. Rand felt a sickness in his stomach at the thought of Trollocs in the streets of Caemlyn. All those people at one another's throats, never realizing the real threat waiting to come over the walls. What would they do when they suddenly found Trollocs and Fades in their midst, killing them? He could see the towers burning, flames breaking through the domes, Trollocs pillaging through the curving streets and vistas of the Inner City. The Palace itself in flames. Elayne, and Gawyn, and Morgase . . . dead.

"nɑt jɛt," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛɾ æbsənli. ʃi wɑz stɪl ɪntɛn ɑn mæt. "ɪf wi kən faɪn ə weɪ aʊɾ ə keɪɛmlɪn, ðə hæfmən wɪl əv noʊ mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəs hɪɹ. ɪf. soʊ mɛni ɪfs."

"Not yet," Moiraine said absently. She was still intent on Mat. "If we can find a way out of Caemlyn, the Halfmen will have no more interest here. If. So many if's."

"bɛɾɝ wi wɝ ɔl dɛd," pɛɹɪn sɛd sʌɾənli, ən ɹænd dʒʌmpt ət ði ɛkoʊ ʌv ɪz oʊn θɔts. pɛɹɪn stɪl sæt stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə flɔɹ - ɡlɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪt naʊ - ən ɪz vɔɪs wɑz bɪɾɝ. "ɛvɹiwɛɹ wi ɡoʊ, wi bɹɪŋ peɪn ən sʌfɝɪŋ ɑn əɹ bæks. ɪt wəd bi bɛɾɝ fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪf wi wɝ dɛd."

"Better we were all dead," Perrin said suddenly, and Rand jumped at the echo of his own thoughts. Perrin still sat staring at the floor - glaring at it now - and his voice was bitter. "Everywhere we go, we bring pain and suffering on our backs. It would be better for everyone if we were dead."

nɪneɪiv ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn hɪm, hɝ feɪs hæf fjʊɹi ən hæf wɝid fɪɹ, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn fɔɹstɑl hɝ.

Nynaeve rounded on him, her face half fury and half worried fear, but Moiraine forestalled her.

"wʌt dʒju θɪŋk tə ɡeɪn, fəɹ jɝsɛlf əɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls, baɪ daɪɪŋ?" ði ɛɛs sədaɪ æskt. hɝ vɔɪs wɑz lɛvəl, jɛt ʃɑɹp. "ɪf ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪv əz ɡeɪn əz mʌtʃ fɹiɾəm tə tʌtʃ ðə pæɾɝn əz aɪ fɪɹ, hi kən ɹitʃ jə dɛd mɔɹ izəli ðən əlaɪv, naʊ. dɛd, jə kən hɛlp noʊ wʌn, nɑt ðə pipəl u hæv hɛlp ju, nɑt jəɹ fɹɛnz ən fæmli bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ðə ʃædoʊ ɪz fɔlɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə wɝld, ən nʌn ə jə kən stɑp ɪt dɛd."

"What do you think to gain, for yourself or anyone else, by dying?" the Aes Sedai asked. Her voice was level, yet sharp. "If the Lord of the Grave has gained as much freedom to touch the Pattern as I fear, he can reach you dead more easily than alive, now. Dead, you can help no one, not the people who have helped you, not your friends and family back in the Two Rivers. The Shadow is falling over the world, and none of you can stop it dead."

pɛɹɪn ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛd tə lʊk ət hɝ, ən ɹænd ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. ði aɪɹəsɪz ə hɪz fɹɛnz aɪz wɝ mɔɹ jɛloʊ ðən bɹaʊn. wɪð ɪz ʃæɡi hɛɹ ən ði ɪntɛnsəɾi ʌv ɪz ɡeɪz, ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt hɪm. . . . ɹænd kəd nɑt ɡɹæsp ɪɾ ɪnʌf tə meɪk ɪɾ aʊt.

Perrin raised his head to look at her, and Rand gave a start. The irises of his friend's eyes were more yellow than brown. With his shaggy hair and the intensity of his gaze, there was something about him. . . . Rand could not grasp it enough to make it out.

pɛɹɪn spoʊk wɪð ə sɑft flætnəs ðət ɡeɪv ɪz wɝdz mɔɹ weɪt ðən ɪf i hæd ʃaʊɾəd. "wi kæn stɑp ɪɾ əlaɪv, iðɝ, naʊ kən wi?"

Perrin spoke with a soft flatness that gave his words more weight than if he had shouted. "We can't stop it alive, either, now can we?"

"aɪ wɪl əv taɪm tə ɑɹɡju wɪð jə leɪɾɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "bʌt jəɹ fɹɛnd nidz mi naʊ." ʃi stɛpt əsaɪd soʊ ðeɪ kəɾ ɔl si mæt klɪɹli. hɪz aɪz stɪl ɑn əɹ wɪð ə ɹeɪdʒ-fɪl stɛɹ, hi hæd nɑt muvd əɹ tʃeɪnʒd ɪz pəzɪʃən ɑn ðə bɛd. swɛt stʊɾ aʊɾ ɑn ɪz feɪs, ən ɪz lɪps wɝ blʌdləs ɪn ən əntʃeɪnʒɪŋ snɑɹl. ɔl ə hɪz stʃɹɛŋkθ sim tə bi pɔɹɪŋ ɪndə ði ɛfɝt tə ɹitʃ mɔɪɹeɪn wɪð ðə dæɡɝ læn hɛl moʊʃənləs. "ɔɹ hæd jə fɝɡɑɾən?"

"I will have time to argue with you later," Moiraine said, "but your friend needs me now." She stepped aside so they could all see Mat clearly. His eyes still on her with a rage-filled stare, he had not moved or changed his position on the bed. Sweat stood out on his face, and his lips were bloodless in an unchanging snarl. All of his strength seemed to be pouring into the effort to reach Moiraine with the dagger Lan held motionless. "Or had you forgotten?"

pɛɹɪn ɡeɪv ən ɪmbɛɹəst ʃɹʌɡ ən spɹɛɾ ɪz hænz wɝdləsli.

Perrin gave an embarrassed shrug and spread his hands wordlessly.

"wʌts ɹɔŋ wɪð hɪm?" ɛɡwin æskt, ən nɪneɪiv æɾəd, "ɪz ɪt kætʃɪŋ? aɪ kən stɪl tʃɹit hɪm. aɪ doʊn sim tə kætʃ sɪk, noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɪɾ ɪz."

"What's wrong with him?" Egwene asked, and Nynaeve added, "Is it catching? I can still treat him. I don't seem to catch sick, no matter what it is."

"oʊ, ɪts kætʃɪŋ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "æn jəɹ . . . pɹətɛkʃən wəd nɑt seɪv ju." ʃi pɔɪntəd tə ðə ɹubi-hɪltɪd dæɡɝ, kɛɹfəl nɑt tə lɛɾ əɹ fɪŋɡɝ tʌtʃ ɪt. ðə bleɪd tʃɹɛmbəld əz mæt stʃɹeɪn tə ɹitʃ əɹ wɪð ɪt. "ðɪs ɪz fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. ðəɹ ɪz nɑɾ ə pɛbəl ə ðət sɪɾi ðəɾ ɪz nɑt teɪntɪɾ ən deɪnʒɝəs tə bɹɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə wɔlz, ən ðɪs ɪz fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ə pɛbəl. ði ivəl ðət kɪld ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ɪz ɪn ɪt, ən ɪn mæt, tu, naʊ. səspɪʃən ən heɪtʃɹəd soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðəɾ ivən ðoʊz kloʊsəst ɑɹ sin əz ɛnəmiz, ɹuɾəd soʊ dip ɪn ðə boʊn ðəɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli ði oʊnli θɔt lɛft ɪz tə kɪl. baɪ kæɹiɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ bɪɑn ðə wɔlz ə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ i fɹiɾ ɪt, ðɪs siɾ ʌv ɪt, fɹəm wʌt baʊn ɪt tə ðət pleɪs. ɪɾəl əv wækst ən weɪn ɪn hɪm, wʌt hiz ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə hɪm faɪɾɪŋ wʌt ðə kənteɪdʒən ə mɑʃəɾɝ sɔt tə meɪk hɪm, bʌt naʊ ðə bæɾəl ɪnsaɪɾ ɪm ɪz ɔlmoʊs dʌn, ən i ɔlmoʊs dɪfiɾəd. sun, ɪf ɪt dʌz nɑt kɪl ɪm fɝst, hɪl spɹɛd ðəɾ ivəl laɪk ə pleɪɡ wɛɹɛvɝ i ɡoʊz. dʒʌst əz wʌn skɹætʃ fɹəm ðət bleɪɾ ɪz ɪnʌf tə ɪnfɛkt ən dɪstʃɹɔɪ, soʊ, sun, ə fju mɪnəts wɪð mæt wɪl bi dʒʌst əz dɛdli."

"Oh, it is catching," Moiraine said, "and your . . . protection would not save you." She pointed to the ruby-hilted dagger, careful not to let her finger touch it. The blade trembled as Mat strained to reach her with it. "This is from Shadar Logoth. There is not a pebble of that city that is not tainted and dangerous to bring outside the walls, and this is far more than a pebble. The evil that killed Shadar Logoth is in it, and in Mat, too, now. Suspicion and hatred so strong that even those closest are seen as enemies, rooted so deep in the bone that eventually the only thought left is to kill. By carrying the dagger beyond the walls of Shadar Logoth he freed it, this seed of it, from what bound it to that place. It will have waxed and waned in him, what he is in the heart of him fighting what the contagion of Mashadar sought to make him, but now the battle inside him is almost done, and he almost defeated. Soon, if it does not kill him first, he will spread that evil like a plague wherever he goes. Just as one scratch from that blade is enough to infect and destroy, so, soon, a few minutes with Mat will be just as deadly."

nɪneɪivz feɪs hæd ɡɔn waɪt. "kæn jə də ɛniθɪŋ?" ʃi wɪspɝd.

Nynaeve's face had gone white. "Can you do anything?" she whispered.

"aɪ hoʊp soʊ." mɔɪɹeɪn saɪd. "fɔɹ ðə seɪk ə ðə wɝld, aɪ hoʊp aɪm nɑt tu leɪt." hɝ hæn dɛlvd ɪndə ðə paʊtʃ əɾ əɹ bɛlt ən keɪm aʊt wɪð ðə sɪlk-ʃɹaʊɾɪd æŋɡɹil. "liv mi. steɪ təɡɛðɝ, ən faɪn sʌmwɛɹ jəl nɑt bi sin, bʌt liv mi. əl də wʌɾ aɪ kən fəɹ hɪm."

"I hope so." Moiraine sighed. "For the sake of the world, I hope I am not too late." Her hand delved into the pouch at her belt and came out with the silk-shrouded angreal. "Leave me. Stay together, and find somewhere you will not be seen, but leave me. I will do what I can for him."


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾitu


CHAPTER 42

ɹimɛmbɹəns ə dʒɹimz


Remembrance of Dreams

ɪt wɑz ə səbdud ɡɹup ðət ɹænd lɛd bæk daʊn ðə stɛɹz. nʌn ə ðɛm wɑntəd tə tɔk tə hɪm naʊ, əɹ tə wʌn ənʌðɝ. hi dɪd nɑt fil mʌtʃ laɪk tɔkɪŋ, iðɝ.

It was a subdued group that Rand led back down the stairs. None of them wanted to talk to him now, or to one another. He did not feel much like talking, either.

ðə sʌn wɑz fɑɹ ɪnʌf əkɹɔs ðə skaɪ tə dɪm ðə bæk stɛɹwɛl, bʌt ðə læmps hæd nɑt jɛt bɪn lɪt. sʌnlaɪɾ ən ʃædoʊ stʃɹaɪp ðə stɛɹz. pɛɹɪnz feɪs wɑz əz kloʊzd əz ði ʌðɝz, bʌt wɛɹ wɝi kɹist ɛvɹiwʌn ɛlsəz bɹaʊ, hɪz wɑz smuð. ɹænd θɔt ðə lʊk pɛɹɪn wɔɹ wɑz ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən. hi wʌndɝd waɪ, ən wɑntəd tə æsk, bʌt wɛnɛvɝ pɛɹɪn wɔk θɹu ə dipɝ pætʃ ə ʃædoʊ, hɪz aɪz sim tə ɡæðɝ ɪn wʌt lɪɾəl laɪt ðəɹ wɑz, ɡloʊɪŋ sɔfli laɪk pɑlɪʃt æmbɝ.

The sun was far enough across the sky to dim the back stairwell, but the lamps had not yet been lit. Sunlight and shadow striped the stairs. Perrin's face was as closed as the others, but where worry creased everyone else's brow, his was smooth. Rand thought the look Perrin wore was resignation. He wondered why, and wanted to ask, but whenever Perrin walked through a deeper patch of shadow, his eyes seemed to gather in what little light there was, glowing softly like polished amber.

ɹænd ʃɪvɝɾ ən tʃɹaɪd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ɪz sɝaʊndɪŋz, ɑn ðə wɔlnʌt pænəld wɔlz ən ði oʊk stɛɹ ɹeɪlɪŋ, ɑn stɝɾi, ɛvɹideɪ θɪŋz. hi waɪpt ɪz hænz ɑn ɪz koʊt sɛvɹəl taɪmz, bʌɾ itʃ taɪm swɛt spɹæŋ aʊɾ ɑn ɪz pɑmz ənu. ɪɾəl ɔl bi ɔl ɹaɪt, naʊ. wɝ təɡɛðɝ əɡɛn, ænd. . . . laɪt, mæt.

Rand shivered and tried to concentrate on his surroundings, on the walnut paneled walls and the oak stair railing, on sturdy, everyday things. He wiped his hands on his coat several times, but each time sweat sprang out on his palms anew. It'll all be all right, now. We're together again, and. . . . Light, Mat.

hi tʊk əm tə ðə laɪbɹɛɹi baɪ ðə bæk weɪ ðət wɛn baɪ ðə kɪtʃənz, əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə kɑmən ɹum. nɑt mɛni tʃɹævəlɝz juz ðə laɪbɹɛɹi; moʊst ə ðoʊz u kəd ɹid steɪɾ ət mɔɹ ɛləɡən ɪnz ɪn ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi. mæstɝ ɡɪl kɛpt ɪt mɔɹ fəɹ ɪz oʊn ɛndʒɔɪmən ðən fəɹ ðə hændfʊl ə peɪtʃɹənz u wɑntəɾ ə bʊk naʊ ən ðɛn. ɹænd dɪd nɑt wɑnə θɪŋk waɪ mɔɪɹeɪn wɑntəɾ əm tə kip aʊɾ ə saɪt, bʌɾ i kɛpt ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðə waɪtkloʊk ʌndɝ-ɔfəsɝ seɪɪŋ i wəd bi bæk, ən ɪleɪɾəz aɪz wən ʃi æskt wɛɹ i wɑz steɪɪŋ. ðoʊz wɝ ɹizənz ɪnʌf, wʌtɛvɝ mɔɪɹeɪn wɑntəd.

He took them to the library by the back way that went by the kitchens, avoiding the common room. Not many travelers used the library; most of those who could read stayed at more elegant inns in the Inner City. Master Gill kept it more for his own enjoyment than for the handful of patrons who wanted a book now and then. Rand did not want to think why Moiraine wanted them to keep out of sight, but he kept remembering the Whitecloak under-officer saying he would be back, and Elaida's eyes when she asked where he was staying. Those were reasons enough, Whatever Moiraine wanted.

hi tʊk faɪv stɛps ɪndə ðə laɪbɹɛɹi bɪfɔɹ i ɹilaɪz ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls hæd stɑpt, kɹaʊɾəd təɡɛðɝ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, oʊpənməðd ən ɡɑəlɪŋ. ə bɹɪsk bleɪz kɹækəld ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪs, ən lɔɪəl wɑz spɹɔld ɑn ðə lɔŋ kaʊtʃ, ɹiɾɪŋ, ə smɔl blæk kæt wɪð waɪt fit kɝld ən hæf əslip ɑn ɪz stʌmək. wən ðeɪ ɛntɝɾ i kloʊz ðə bʊk wɪð ə hjudʒ fɪŋɡɝ mɑɹkɪŋ ɪz pleɪs ən dʒɛnli sɛt ðə kæɾ ɑn ðə flɔɹ, ðən stʊd tə baʊ fɔɹməli.

He took five steps into the library before he realized that everyone else had stopped, crowded together in the doorway, openmouthed and goggling. A brisk blaze crackled in the fireplace, and Loial was sprawled on the long couch, reading, a small black cat with white feet curled and half asleep on his stomach. When they entered he closed the book with a huge finger marking his place and gently set the cat on the floor, then stood to bow formally.

ɹænd wɑz soʊ juz tə ði oʊɡiɝ ðəɾ ɪt tʊk ɪm ə mɪnət tə ɹilaɪz ðət lɔɪəl wɑz ði əbdʒɛkt ə ði ʌðɝz' stɛɹz. "ðiz ɑɹ ðə fɹɛnz aɪ wɑz weɪɾɪŋ fɔɹ, lɔɪəl," hi sɛd. "ðɪs ɪz nɪneɪiv, ðə wɪzdəm ə maɪ vɪlədʒ. ən pɛɹɪn. ən ðɪs ɪz ɛɡwin."

Rand was so used to the Ogier that it took him a minute to realize that Loial was the object of the others' stares. "These are the friends I was waiting for, Loial," he said. "This is Nynaeve, the Wisdom of my village. And Perrin. And this is Egwene."

"ɑ, jɛs," lɔɪəl bumd, "ɛɡwin. ɹænd əz spoʊkən ə jə ə ɡɹeɪt dil. jɛs. aɪm lɔɪəl."

"Ah, yes," Loial boomed, "Egwene. Rand has spoken of you a great deal. Yes. I am Loial."

"hiz ən oʊɡiɝ," ɹænd ɪkspleɪnd, ən wɑtʃt ðɛɹ əmeɪzmən tʃeɪnʒ ɪn kaɪnd. ivən æftɝ tʃɹɑləks ən feɪdz ɪn ðə flɛʃ, ɪt wɑz stɪl əstɑnɪʃɪŋ tə miɾ ə lɛdʒənd wɔkɪŋ ən bɹiðɪŋ. ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ɪz oʊn fɝst ɹiækʃən tə lɔɪəl, hi ɡɹɪn ɹufəli. ðeɪ wɝ duɪŋ bɛɾɝ ðən i hæd.

"He's an Ogier," Rand explained, and watched their amazement change in kind. Even after Trollocs and Fades in the flesh, it was still astonishing to meet a legend walking and breathing. Remembering his own first reaction to Loial, he grinned ruefully. They were doing better than he had.

lɔɪəl tʊk ðɛɹ ɡeɪpɪŋ ɪn ɪz stʃɹaɪd. ɹænd səpoʊzd i hɑɹdli noʊɾəst ɪt kəmpɛɹd wɪð ə mɑb ʃaʊɾɪŋ "tʃɹɑlɑk." "æn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ɹænd?" lɔɪəl æskt.

Loial took their gaping in his stride. Rand supposed he hardly noticed it compared with a mob shouting "Trolloc." "And the Aes Sedai, Rand?" Loial asked.

"əpstɛɹz wɪð mæt."

"Upstairs with Mat."

ði oʊɡiɝ ɹeɪzd wʌn bʊʃi aɪbɹaʊ θɔtfəli. "ðɛn hiz ɪl. aɪ sədʒɛst wi ɔl bi siɾəd. ʃɪl bi dʒɔɪnɪŋ ʌs? jɛs. ðən ðɛɹz nʌθɪŋ tə də bʌt weɪt."

The Ogier raised one bushy eyebrow thoughtfully. "Then he is ill. I suggest we all be seated. She will be joining us? Yes. Then there's nothing to do but wait."

ði ækt ə sɪɾɪŋ sim tə lusən səm kætʃ ɪnsaɪd ði ɛmənz fil foʊk, əz ɪf biɪŋ ɪn ə wɛl-stʌf tʃɛɹ wɪð ə faɪɝ ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪs ən ə kæt naʊ kɝld ʌp ɑn ðə hɑɹθ meɪɾ əm fil ət hoʊm. əz sun əz ðeɪ wɝ sɛɾəld ðeɪ ɪksaɪɾədli bɪɡæn æskɪŋ ði oʊɡiɝ kwɛstʃənz. tə ɹændz sɝpɹaɪz, pɛɹɪn wɑz ðə fɝs tə spik.

The act of sitting seemed to loosen some catch inside the Emond's Field folk, as if being in a well-stuffed chair with a fire in the fireplace and a cat now curled up on the hearth made them feel at home. As soon as they were settled they excitedly began asking the Ogier questions. To Rand's surprise, Perrin was the first to speak.

"ðə stɛɾɪŋ, lɔɪəl. ɑɹ ðeɪ ɹɪli heɪvənz, ðə weɪ ðə stɔɹiz seɪ?" hɪz vɔɪs wɑz ɪntɛnt, əz ɪf i hæɾ ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ ɹizən fəɹ æskɪŋ.

"The stedding, Loial. Are they really havens, the way the stories say?" His voice was intent, as if he had a particular reason for asking.

lɔɪəl wɑz ɡlæd tə tɛl əbaʊt ðə stɛɾɪŋ, ən haʊ hi keɪm tə bi ət ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ, ən wʌɾ i hæd sin ɪn ɪz tʃɹævəlz. ɹænd sun lin bæk, oʊnli pɑɹtli lɪsnɪŋ. hi hæd hɝɾ ɪɾ ɔl bɪfɔɹ, ɪn dɪteɪl. lɔɪəl laɪk tə tɔk, ən tɔk ət lɛŋθ wən i hæd ðə slaɪɾəst tʃæns, ðoʊ hi juʒəwəli sim tə θɪŋk ə stɔɹi niɾəd tu əɹ θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ə bækɡɹaʊn tə meɪk ɪɾ ʌndɝstʊd. hɪz sɛns ə taɪm wɑz vɛɹi stʃɹeɪnʒ; tə hɪm θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz simd ə ɹizənəbəl lɛŋθ ə taɪm fəɹ ə stɔɹi əɹ ɛkspləneɪʃən tə kʌvɝ. hi ɔlweɪz tɔkt əbaʊt livɪŋ ðə stɛɾɪŋ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ dʒʌst ə fju mʌnθs bɪfɔɹ, bʌɾ ɪt hæd faɪnəli kʌm aʊt ðəɾ i hæd bɪn ɡɔn mɔɹ ðən θɹi jɪɹz.

Loial was glad to tell about the stedding, and how he came to be at The Queen's Blessing, and what he had seen in his travels. Rand soon leaned back, only partly listening. He had heard it all before, in detail. Loial liked to talk, and talk at length when he had the slightest chance, though he usually seemed to think a story needed two or three hundred years of background to make it understood. His sense of time was very strange; to him three hundred years seemed a reasonable length of time for a story or explanation to cover. He always talked about leaving the stedding as if it were just a few months before, but it had finally come out that he had been gone more than three years.

ɹændz θɔts dʒɹɪftəd tə mæt. ə dæɡɝ. ə blʌɾi naɪf, ən ɪt maɪt kɪl ɪm dʒʌs fɹəm kæɹiɪŋ ɪt. laɪt, aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɛni mɔɹ ædvɛntʃɝ. ɪf ʃi kən hil hɪm, wi ʃəɾ ɔl ɡoʊ . . . nɑt hoʊm. kænt ɡoʊ hoʊm. sʌmwɛɹ. wɪl ɔl ɡoʊ sʌmwɛɹ ðeɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ əɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. sʌmwɛɹ.

Rand's thoughts drifted to Mat. A dagger. A bloody knife, and it might kill him just from carrying it. Light, I don't want any more adventure. If she can heal him, we should all go . . . not home. Can't go home. Somewhere. We'll all go somewhere they've never heard of Aes Sedai or the Dark One. Somewhere.

ðə dɔɹ oʊpənd, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən ɹænd θɔɾ i wɑz stɪl ɪmædʒənɪŋ. mæt stʊd ðɛɹ, blɪŋkɪŋ, wɪð ɪz koʊt bʌɾənd ʌp ən ðə dɑɹk skɑɹf ɹæp loʊ ɝaʊn ɪz fɔɹhɛd. ðən ɹænd sɔ mɔɪɹeɪn, wɪð əɹ hæn ɑn mæts ʃoʊldɝ, ən læn bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ mæt kɛɹfəli, əz wʌn wɑtʃəz sʌmwʌn oʊnli leɪtli aʊɾ ʌv ə sɪkbd. əz ɔlweɪz, læn wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ waɪl əpɪɹɪŋ tə wɑtʃ nʌθɪŋ.

The door opened, and for a moment Rand thought he was still imagining. Mat stood there, blinking, with his coat buttoned up and the dark scarf wrapped low around his forehead. Then Rand saw Moiraine, with her hand on Mat's shoulder, and Lan behind them. The Aes Sedai was watching Mat carefully, as one watches someone only lately out of a sickbed. As always, Lan was watching everything while appearing to watch nothing.

mæt lʊkt əz ɪf i hæd nɛvɝ bɪn sɪk ə deɪ. hɪz fɝst, hɛzɪɾənt smaɪl ɪnkluɾəd ɛvɹiwʌn, ðoʊ ɪt slɪpt ɪndə ən oʊpənməð stɛɹ ət ðə saɪɾ ə lɔɪəl, əz ɪf i wɝ siɪŋ ði oʊɡiɝ fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm. wɪð ə ʃɹʌɡ ən ə ʃeɪk, hi tɝn ɪz ətɛnʃən bæk tə hɪz fɹɛnz. "aɪ . . . ɑ . . . ðəɾ ɪz. . . ." hi tʊk ə dip bɹɛθ. "ɪt . . . ɑ . . . ɪt simz aɪv bɪn æktɪŋ . . . ɑ . . . sɔɹɾ ʌv ɑdli. aɪ doʊn ɹɪmɛmbɝ mʌtʃ ʌv ɪt, ɹɪli." hi ɡeɪv mɔɪɹeɪn ən ənizi lʊk. ʃi smaɪl bæk kɑnfəɾəntli, ən i wɛn ɑn. "ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪz heɪzi æftɝ waɪtbɹɪdʒ. tɑm, ən ðə. . . ." hi ʃɪvɝɾ ən hɝiɾ ɑn. "ðə fɝðɝ fɹəm waɪtbɹɪdʒ, ðə heɪziɝ ɪt ɡɛts. aɪ doʊn ɹɪli ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɝaɪvɪŋ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn əɾ ɔl." hi aɪd lɔɪəl əskæns. "nɑt ɹɪli. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛz aɪ . . . əpstɛɹz, aɪ . . . ɑ. . . ." hi ɡɹɪnd, ən sʌɾənli hi tʃɹuli wɑz ði oʊl mæt. "ju kæn hoʊld ə mæn tə bleɪm fəɹ wʌɾ i dʌz wən hiz kɹeɪzi, kən ju?"

Mat looked as if he had never been sick a day. His first, hesitant smile included everyone, though it slipped into an openmouthed stare at the sight of Loial, as if he were seeing the Ogier for the first time. With a shrug and a shake, he turned his attention back to his friends. "I . . . ah . . . that is. . . ." He took a deep breath. "It . . . ah . . . it seems I've been acting . . . ah . . . sort of oddly. I don't remember much of it, really." He gave Moiraine an uneasy look. She smiled back confidently, and he went on. "Everything is hazy after Whitebridge. Thom, and the. . . ." He shivered and hurried on. "The further from Whitebridge, the hazier it gets. I don't really remember arriving in Caemlyn at all." He eyed Loial askance. "Not really. Moiraine Sedai says I . . . upstairs, I . . . ah. . . ." He grinned, and suddenly he truly was the old Mat. "You can't hold a man to blame for what he does when he's crazy, can you?"

"ju ɔlweɪz wɝ kɹeɪzi," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ən fəɹ ə moʊmən hi, tu, saʊndəɾ əz ʌv oʊld.

"You always were crazy," Perrin said, and for a moment he, too, sounded as of old.

"noʊ," nɪneɪiv sɛd. tɪɹz meɪɾ əɹ aɪz bɹaɪt, bʌt ʃi wɑz smaɪlɪŋ. "nʌn ʌv əs bleɪmz ju."

"No," Nynaeve said. Tears made her eyes bright, but she was smiling. "None of us blames you."

ɹænd ən ɛɡwin bɪɡæn tɔkɪŋ ət wʌns ðɛn, tɛlɪŋ mæt haʊ hæpi ðeɪ wɝ tə si hɪm wɛl ən haʊ wɛl i lʊkt, wɪð ə fju læfɪŋ kɑmɛns θɹoʊn ɪn əbaʊt hoʊpɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz dʌn wɪð tʃɹɪks naʊ ðət wʌn soʊ ʌɡli hæd bɪn pleɪɾ ɑn hɪm. mæt mɛt bæntɝ wɪð bæntɝ əz i faʊn ə tʃɛɹ wɪð ɔl ə hɪz oʊl swæɡɝ. əz i sæt daʊn, stɪl ɡɹɪnɪŋ, hi æbsəntmaɪndɪdli tʌtʃt ɪz koʊɾ əz ɪf tə meɪk ʃʊɹ ðət sʌmθɪŋ tʌk bɪhaɪn ɪz bɛlt wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, ən ɹændz bɹɛθ kɑt.

Rand and Egwene began talking at once then, telling Mat how happy they were to see him well and how well he looked, with a few laughing comments thrown in about hoping that he was done with tricks now that one so ugly had been played on him. Mat met banter with banter as he found a chair with all of his old swagger. As he sat down, still grinning, he absentmindedly touched his coat as if to make sure that something tucked behind his belt was still there, and Rand's breath caught.

"jɛs," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd kwaɪətli, "hi stɪl əz ðə dæɡɝ." ðə læftɝ ən tɔk wɑz stɪl ɡoʊɪŋ ɑn əmʌŋ ðə ɹɛst ə ði ɛmənz fil foʊk, bʌt ʃi hæd noʊɾəst ɪz sʌɾən ɪnteɪk ə bɹɛθ ən hæd sin wʌt hæd kɑzd ɪt. ʃi muv kloʊsɝ tə hɪz tʃɛɹ, wɛɹ ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə ɹeɪz əɹ vɔɪs fəɹ ɪm tə hɪɹ klɪɹli. "aɪ kænɑt teɪk ɪɾ əweɪ fɹəm ɪm wɪθaʊt kɪlɪŋ hɪm. ðə baɪndɪŋ əz læstəd tu lɔŋ, ən ɡɹoʊn tu stʃɹɔŋ. ðət mʌs bi ənnɑɾɪd ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn; ɪts bɪɑn mi, əɹ ɛni loʊn ɛɛs sədaɪ, ivən wɪð ən æŋɡɹil."

"Yes," Moiraine said quietly, "he still has the dagger." The laughter and talk was still going on among the rest of the Emond's Field folk, but she had noticed his sudden intake of breath and had seen what had caused it. She moved closer to his chair, where she did not have to raise her voice for him to hear clearly. "I cannot take it away from him without killing him. The binding has lasted too long, and grown too strong. That must be unknotted in Tar Valon; it is beyond me, or any lone Aes Sedai, even with an angreal."

"bʌɾ i dʌzn lʊk sɪk ɛnimɔɹ." hi hæɾ ə θɔɾ ən lʊkt ʌp ət hɝ. "æz lɔŋ əz hiz ðə dæɡɝ, ðə feɪdz wɪl noʊ wɛɹ wi ɑɹ. dɑɹkfɹɛnz, tu, səm ə ðɛm. jə sɛd soʊ."

"But he doesn't look sick anymore." He had a thought and looked up at her. "As long as he has the dagger, the Fades will know where we are. Darkfriends, too, some of them. You said so."

"aɪ hæv kənteɪn ðæt, æftɝ ə fæʃən. ɪf ðeɪ kʌm kloʊs ɪnʌf tə sɛns ɪt naʊ, ðəl bi ɑn tɑp ʌv əs ɛniweɪ. aɪ klɛnz ðə teɪn fɹəm hɪm, ɹænd, ən dɪd wʌɾ aɪ kəd tə sloʊ ɪts ɹɪtɝn, bʌt ɹɪtɝn ɪt wɪl, ɪn taɪm, ənlɛs i ɹəsivz hɛlp ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn."

"I have contained that, after a fashion. If they come close enough to sense it now, they will be on top of us anyway. I cleansed the taint from him, Rand, and did what I could to slow its return, but return it will, in time, unless he receives help in Tar Valon."

"ə ɡʊd θɪŋ ðæts wɛɹ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ, ɪzən ɪt?" hi θɔt meɪbi ɪt wɑz ðə ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən ɪn ɪz vɔɪs, ən ðə hoʊp fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, ðət meɪɾ əɹ ɡɪv ɪm ə ʃɑɹp lʊk bɪfɔɹ tɝnɪŋ əweɪ.

"A good thing that's where we're going, isn't it?" He thought maybe it was the resignation in his voice, and the hope for something else, that made her give him a sharp look before turning away.

lɔɪəl wɑz ɑn ɪz fit, boʊɪŋ tə hɝ. "aɪ æm lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹən sʌn ə hɑlən, ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə stɛɾɪŋ ɔfɝz sæŋktʃuɛɹi tə ðə sɝvəns ə ðə laɪt."

Loial was on his feet, bowing to her. "I am Loial, son of Arent son of Halan, Aes Sedai. The stedding offers sanctuary to the Servants of the Light."

"θæŋk ju, lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹənt," mɔɪɹeɪn ænsɝd dʒɹaɪli, "bʌɾ aɪ wəd nɑt bi tu fɹi wɪð ðət ɡɹiɾɪŋ ɪf aɪ wɝ ju. ðəɹ ɑɹ pɝhæps twɛnti ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn ət ðɪs moʊmənt, ən ɛvɹi wʌn bʌɾ aɪ ʌv ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ." lɔɪəl nɑɾəd sədʒli, əz ɪf i ʌndɝstʊd. ɹænd kəɾ oʊnli ʃeɪk ɪz hɛɾ ɪn kənfjuʒən; hi wəd bi laɪtblɪndɪɾ ɪf i nu wʌt ʃi mɛnt. "ɪɾ ɪz stʃɹeɪnʒ tə faɪn jə hɪɹ," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛn ɑn. "fju oʊɡiɝ liv ðə stɛɾɪŋ ɪn ɹisən jɪɹz."

"Thank you, Loial, son of Arent," Moiraine answered dryly, "but I would not be too free with that greeting if I were you. There are perhaps twenty Aes Sedai in Caemlyn at this moment, and every one but I of the Red Ajah." Loial nodded sagely, as if he understood. Rand could only shake his head in confusion; he would be Lightblinded if he knew what she meant. "It is strange to find you here," the Aes Sedai went on. "Few Ogier leave the stedding in recent years."

"ði oʊl stɔɹiz kɑt mi, ɛɛs sədaɪ. ði oʊl bʊks fɪl maɪ ənwɝði hɛd wɪð pɪktʃɝz. aɪ wɑnə si ðə ɡɹoʊvz. ən ðə sɪɾiz wi bɪlt, tu. ðəɹ də nɑt sim tə bi mɛni ʌv iðɝ stɪl stændɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪf bɪldɪŋz ɑɹ ə pʊɹ sʌbstətut fəɹ tʃɹiz, ðeɪ ɑɹ stɪl wɝθ siɪŋ. ði ɛldɝz θɪŋk aɪm ɑd, wɑntɪŋ tə tʃɹævəl. aɪ ɔlweɪz hæv, ən ðeɪ ɔlweɪz hæv. nʌn ə ðɛm bɪliv ðəɹ ɪz ɛniθɪŋ wɝθ siɪŋ aʊtsaɪd ðə stɛɾɪŋ. pɝhæps wən aɪ ɹɪtɝn ən tɛl əm wʌɾ aɪv sin, ðəl tʃeɪnʒ ðɛɹ maɪnz. aɪ hoʊp soʊ. ɪn taɪm."

"The old stories caught me, Aes Sedai. The old books filled my unworthy head with pictures. I want to see the groves. And the cities we built, too. There do not seem to be many of either still standing, but if buildings are a poor substitute for trees, they are still worth seeing. The Elders think I'm odd, wanting to travel. I always have, and they always have. None of them believe there is anything worth seeing outside the stedding. Perhaps when I return and tell them what I've seen, they will change their minds. I hope so. In time."

"pɝhæps ðeɪ wɪl," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd smuðli. "naʊ, lɔɪəl, jə mʌs fɝɡɪv mi fəɹ biɪŋ əbɹʌpt. ɪts ə feɪlɪŋ ə hjumənkaɪnd, aɪ noʊ. maɪ kəmpænjənz ən aɪ hæv ɝdʒənt nid tə plæn əɹ dʒɝni. ɪf jə kəɾ ɪkskjuz ʌs?"

"Perhaps they will," Moiraine said smoothly. "Now, Loial, you must forgive me for being abrupt. It is a failing of humankind, I know. My companions and I have urgent need to plan our journey. If you could excuse us?"

ɪt wɑz lɔɪəlz tɝn tə lʊk kənfjuzd. ɹænd keɪm tə hɪz ɹɛskju. "hiz kʌmɪŋ wɪð ʌs. aɪ pɹɑməst ɪm i kʊd."

It was Loial's turn to look confused. Rand came to his rescue. "He's coming with us. I promised him he could."

mɔɪɹeɪn stʊd lʊkɪŋ ət ði oʊɡiɝ əz ɪf ʃi hæd nɑt hɝd, bʌt faɪnəli ʃi nɑɾəd. "ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz," ʃi mɝmɝd. "læn, si ðət wəɹ nɑt teɪkən ʌnəwɛɹ." ðə wɔɹɾɝ vænɪʃt fɹəm ðə ɹum, saɪlənli bʌt fəɹ ðə klɪk ə ðə dɔɹ ʃʌɾɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm.

Moiraine stood looking at the Ogier as if she had not heard, but finally she nodded. "The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills," she murmured. "Lan, see that we are not taken unaware." The Warder vanished from the room, silently but for the click of the door shutting behind him.

lænz dɪsəpɪɹəns æktəd laɪk ə sɪɡnəl; ɔl tɔk wɑz kʌɾ ɔf. mɔɪɹeɪn muv tə ðə faɪɝpleɪs, ən wən ʃi tɝn bæk tə ðə ɹum ɛvɹi aɪ wɑz ɑn hɝ. slaɪɾ ə bɪld əz ʃi wɑz, hɝ pɹɛzəns dɑməneɪɾəd. "wi kænɑt ɹɪmeɪn lɔŋ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, nɔɹ ɑɹ wi seɪf hɪɹ ɪn ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ. ðə dɑɹk wʌnz aɪz ɑɹ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪn ðə sɪɾi. ðeɪv nɑt faʊnd wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ sɝtʃɪŋ fɔɹ, əɹ ðeɪ wəd nɑt stɪl bi lʊkɪŋ. ðət wɪv tə əɹ ædvæntɪdʒ. aɪ hæv sɛt wɔɹdz tə kip əm əweɪ, ən baɪ ðə taɪm ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɹiəlaɪzɪz ðət ðəɹ ɪz ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə sɪɾi ðə ɹæts noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɛntɝ, wɪl bi ɡɔn. ɛni wɔɹd ðət wɪl tɝn ə mæn əsaɪd, ðoʊ, wəd bi əz ɡʊɾ əz ə bikən faɪɝ fəɹ ðə mɹdʒɹɑl, ən ðəɹ ɑɹ tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪɾ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, ɔlsoʊ, lʊkɪŋ fəɹ pɛɹɪn ən ɛɡwin." ɹænd meɪɾ ə saʊnd, ən mɔɪɹeɪn ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət hɪm.

Lan's disappearance acted like a signal; all talk was cut off. Moiraine moved to the fireplace, and when she turned back to the room every eye was on her. Slight of build as she was, her presence dominated. "We cannot remain long in Caemlyn, nor are we safe here in The Queen's Blessing. The Dark One's eyes are already in the city. They have not found what they are searching for, or they would not still be looking. That we have to our advantage. I have set wards to keep them away, and by the time the Dark One realizes that there is a part of the city the rats no longer enter, we will be gone. Any ward that will turn a man aside, though, would be as good as a beacon fire for the Myrddraal, and there are Children of the Light in Caemlyn, also, looking for Perrin and Egwene." Rand made a sound, and Moiraine raised an eyebrow at him.

"aɪ θɔt ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ mæt ən mi," hi sɛd.

"I thought they were looking for Mat and me," he said.

ði ɛkspləneɪʃən meɪd boʊθ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz aɪbɹaʊz lɪft. "waɪ wəd jə θɪŋk ðə waɪtkloʊks wɝ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ ju?"

The explanation made both the Aes Sedai's eyebrows lift. "Why would you think the Whitecloaks were looking for you?"

"aɪ hɝd wʌn seɪ ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ fəɹ sʌmwʌn fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. dɑɹkfɹɛnz, hi sɛd. wʌɾ ɛls wɑz aɪ səpoʊz tə θɪŋk? wɪð ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðæts bɪn hæpənɪŋ, aɪm lʌki aɪ kən θɪŋk əɾ ɔl."

"I heard one say they were looking for someone from the Two Rivers. Darkfriends, he said. What else was I supposed to think? With everything that's been happening, I'm lucky I can think at all."

"ɪɾ əz bɪn kənfjuzɪŋ, aɪ noʊ, ɹænd," lɔɪəl pʊɾ ɪn, "bʌt jə kən θɪŋk mɔɹ klɪɹli ðən ðæt. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən heɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪleɪɾə wəd nɑt - "

"It has been confusing, I know, Rand," Loial put in, "but you can think more clearly than that. The Children hate Aes Sedai. Elaida would not - "

"ɪleɪɾə?" mɔɪɹeɪn kʌɾ ɪn ʃɑɹpli. "wʌɾ əz ɪleɪɾə sədaɪ tə də wɪð ðɪs?"

"Elaida?" Moiraine cut in sharply. "What has Elaida Sedai to do with this?"

ʃi wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət ɹænd soʊ hɑɹd ðəɾ i wɑntəd tə lin bæk. "ʃi wɑntəd tə θɹoʊ mi ɪn pɹɪzən," hi sɛd sloʊli. "ɔl aɪ wɑntəd wɑz ə lʊk ət lɑɡən, bʌt ʃi wʊdn bɪliv aɪ wɑz ɪn ðə pæləs ɡɑɹɾənz wɪð ɪleɪn ən ɡɔɪn dʒʌs baɪ tʃæns." ðeɪ wɝ ɔl stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪm əz ɪf i hæd sʌɾənli spɹaʊɾəd ə θɝɾ aɪ, ɔl ɪksɛp lɔɪəl. "kwin mɔɹɡeɪs lemi ɡoʊ. ʃi sɛd ðəɹ wɑz noʊ pɹuf aɪ mɛn ɛni hɑɹm ən ʃi wɑz gɑnə əphoʊl ðə lɔ noʊ mæɾɝ wʌɾ ɪleɪɾə səspɛktəd." hi ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, ðə mɛmɹi ʌv mɔɹɡeɪs ɪn ɔl əɹ ɹeɪdʒjəns meɪkɪŋ ɪm fɝɡɛt fəɹ ə mɪnət ðəɾ ɛniwʌn wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. "kæn jə ɪmædʒən mi miɾɪŋ ə kwin? ʃiz bjuɾəfəl, laɪk ðə kwinz ɪn stɔɹiz. soʊ ɪz ɪleɪn. ən ɡɔɪn . . . jud laɪk ɡɔɪn, pɛɹɪn. pɛɹɪn? mæt?" ðeɪ wɝ stɪl stɛɹɪŋ. "blʌɾ ən æʃəz, aɪ dʒʌs klaɪmd ʌp ɑn ðə wɔl fəɹ ə lʊk ət ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. aɪ dɪdn də ɛniθɪŋ ɹɔŋ."

She was looking at Rand so hard that he wanted to lean back. "She wanted to throw me in prison," he said slowly. "All I wanted was a look at Logain, but she wouldn't believe I was in the Palace gardens with Elayne and Gawyn just by chance." They were all staring at him as if he had suddenly sprouted a third eye, all except Loial. "Queen Morgase let me go. She said there was no proof I meant any harm and she was going to uphold the law no matter what Elaida suspected." He shook his head, the memory of Morgase in all her radiance making him forget for a minute that anyone was looking at him. "Can you imagine me meeting a Queen? She's beautiful, like the queens in stories. So is Elayne. And Gawyn . . . you'd like Gawyn, Perrin. Perrin? Mat?" They were still staring. "Blood and ashes, I just climbed up on the wall for a look at the false Dragon. I didn't do anything wrong."

"ðæts wʌɾ aɪ ɔlweɪz seɪ," mæt sɛd blænli, ðoʊ hi wɑz sʌɾənli ɡɹɪnɪŋ hɑɹd, ən ɛɡwin æskt ɪn ə dɪsaɪɾədli nutʃɹəl vɔɪs, "huz ɪleɪn?"

"That's what I always say," Mat said blandly, though he was suddenly grinning hard, and Egwene asked in a decidedly neutral voice, "Who's Elayne?"

mɔɪɹeɪn mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ kɹɑsli.

Moiraine muttered something crossly.

"eɪ kwin," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd. "ju ɹɪli hæv hæɾ ædvɛntʃɝz. ɔl wi mɛt wɝ tɪŋkɝz ən səm waɪtkloʊks." hi əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət mɔɪɹeɪn soʊ ɑbviəsli ðət ɹænd sɔ ði əvɔɪɾəns pleɪn. pɛɹɪn tʌtʃt ðə bɹuzəz ɑn ɪz feɪs. "ɑn ðə hoʊl, sɪŋɪŋ wɪð ðə tɪŋkɝz wɑz mɔɹ fʌn ðən ðə waɪtkloʊks."

"A Queen," Perrin said, shaking his head. "You really have had adventures. All we met were Tinkers and some Whitecloaks." He avoided looking at Moiraine so obviously that Rand saw the avoidance plain. Perrin touched the bruises on his face. "On the whole, singing with the Tinkers was more fun than the Whitecloaks."

"ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl lɪv fəɹ ðɛɹ sɔŋz," lɔɪəl sɛd. "fɔɹ ɔl sɔŋz, fəɹ ðət mæɾɝ. fəɹ ðə sɝtʃ fəɹ ðɛm, ət list. aɪ mɛt səm tuætɑn ə fju jɪɹz bæk, ən ðeɪ wɑntəd tə lɝn ðə sɔŋz wi sɪŋ tə tʃɹiz. æktʃəli , ðə tʃɹiz woʊn lɪsən tə vɛɹi mɛni ɛnimɔɹ, ən soʊ nɑt mɛni oʊɡiɝ lɝn ðə sɔŋz. aɪ hæv ə skɹæp ə ðət tælənt, soʊ ɛldɝ ɑɹən ɪnsɪstəɾ aɪ lɝn. aɪ tɔt ðə tuætɑn wʌt ðeɪ kəd lɝn, bʌt ðə tʃɹiz nɛvɝ lɪsən tə hjumənz. fəɹ ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl ðeɪ wɝ oʊnli sɔŋz, ən dʒʌst əz wɛl ɹəsiv fəɹ ðæt, sɪns nʌn wɑz ðə sɔŋ ðeɪ sik. ðæts wʌt ðeɪ kɔl ðə liɾɝ ʌv itʃ bænd, ðə sikɝ. ðeɪ kʌm tə stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ, səmtaɪmz. fju hjumənz du."

"The Traveling People live for their songs," Loial said. "For all songs, for that matter. For the search for them, at least. I met some Tuatha'an a few years back, and they wanted to learn the songs we sing to trees. Actually, the trees won't listen to very many anymore, and so not many Ogier learn the songs. I have a scrap of that Talent, so Elder Arent insisted I learn. I taught the Tuatha'an what they could learn, but the trees never listen to humans. For the Traveling People they were only songs, and just as well received for that, since none was the song they seek. That's what they call the leader of each band, the Seeker. They come to Stedding Shangtai, sometimes. Few humans do."

"ɪf jə pliz, lɔɪəl," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, bʌɾ i klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt sʌɾənli ən wɛn ɑn ɪn ə kwɪk ɹʌmbəl əz ɪf əfɹeɪd ʃi maɪt stɑp hɪm.

"If you please, Loial," Moiraine said, but he cleared his throat suddenly and went on in a quick rumble as if afraid she might stop him.

"aɪv dʒʌst ɹɪmɛmbɝd sʌmθɪŋ, ɛɛs sədaɪ, sʌmθɪŋ aɪ hæv ɔlweɪz wɑntəd tə æsk ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪf ɛvɝ aɪ mɛt wʌn, sɪns jə noʊ mɛni θɪŋz ən əv ɡɹeɪt laɪbɹɛɹiz ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən naʊ aɪ hæv, ʌv kɔɹs, ən . . . meɪ aɪ?"

"I've just remembered something, Aes Sedai, something I have always wanted to ask an Aes Sedai if ever I met one, since you know many things and have great libraries in Tar Valon, and now I have, of course, and . . . may I?"

"ɪf jə meɪk ɪt bɹif," ʃi sɛd kɝtli.

"If you make it brief," she said curtly.

"bɹif," hi sɛɾ əz ðoʊ wʌndɝɪŋ wʌɾ ɪt mɛnt. "jɛs. wɛl. bɹif. ðəɹ wɑz ə mæn keɪm tə stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ ə lɪɾəl taɪm bæk. ðɪs wɑz nɑɾ ənjuʒəwəl ɪn ɪtsɛlf, ət ðə taɪm, sɪns ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni ɹɛfjudʒiz hæd kʌm tə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝl fliɪŋ wʌt jə hjumənz kɔl ði il wɔɹ." ɹænd ɡɹɪnd. ə lɪɾəl taɪm bæk; twɛnti jɪɹz, nɪɹ ɪnʌf. "hi wɑz ət ðə pɔɪn ə dɛθ, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ waʊn əɹ mɑɹk ɑn hɪm. ði ɛldɝz θɔɾ ɪt maɪt bi sʌmθɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ hæd dʌn" - lɔɪəl ɡeɪv mɔɪɹeɪn ən əpɑlədʒɛɾɪk lʊk - "sɪns əz sun əz i wɑz wɪðɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ i kwɪkli ɡɑt wɛl. ə fju mʌnθs. wʌn naɪɾ i lɛft wɪθaʊɾ ə wɝd tə ɛniwʌn, sɪmpli snikt əweɪ wən ðə mun wɑz daʊn." hi lʊkt ət mɔɪɹeɪnz feɪs ən klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊɾ əɡɛn. "jɛs. bɹif. bɪfɔɹ i lɛft, hi toʊld ə kjʊɹiəs teɪl wɪtʃ i sɛɾ i mɛn tə kæɹi tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. hi sɛd ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪntɛndəd tə blaɪn ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld, ən sleɪ ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpənt, kɪl taɪm ɪtsɛlf. ði ɛldɝz sɛɾ i wɑz əz saʊn ɪn ɪz maɪn əz ɪn ɪz bɑɾi, bʌt ðət wɑz wʌɾ i sɛd. wʌɾ aɪ hæv wɑntəd tə æsk ɪz, kən ðə dɑɹk wʌn də sətʃ ə θɪŋ? kɪl taɪm ɪtsɛlf? ən ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld? kən i blaɪn ði aɪ ʌv ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpənt? wʌt dʌz ɪt min?"

"Brief," he said as though wondering what it meant. "Yes. Well. Brief. There was a man came to Stedding Shangtai a little time back. This was not unusual in itself, at the time, since a great many refugees had come to the Spine of the World fleeing what you humans call the Aiel War." Rand grinned. A little time back; twenty years, near enough. "He was at the point of death, though there was no wound or mark on him. The Elders thought it might be something Aes Sedai had done" - Loial gave Moiraine an apologetic look - "since as soon as he was within the stedding he quickly got well. A few months. One night he left without a word to anyone, simply sneaked away when the moon was down." He looked at Moiraine's face and cleared his throat again. "Yes. Brief. Before he left, he told a curious tale which he said he meant to carry to Tar Valon. He said the Dark One intended to blind the Eye of the World, and slay the Great Serpent, kill time itself. The Elders said he was as sound in his mind as in his body, but that was what he said. What I have wanted to ask is, can the Dark One do such a thing? Kill time itself? And the Eye of the World? Can he blind the eye of the Great Serpent? What does it mean?"

ɹænd ɪkspɛktəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɛniθɪŋ fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪn ɪksɛpt wʌɾ i sɔ. ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɡɪvɪŋ lɔɪəl ən ænsɝ, əɹ tɛlɪŋ ɪm ʃi hæd noʊ taɪm fəɹ ɪt naʊ, ʃi stʊd ðəɹ stɛɹɪŋ ɹaɪt θɹu ði oʊɡiɝ, fɹaʊnɪŋ ɪn θɔt.

Rand expected almost anything from Moiraine except what he saw. Instead of giving Loial an answer, or telling him she had no time for it now, she stood there staring right through the Ogier, frowning in thought.

"ðæts wʌt ðə tɪŋkɝz toʊld ʌs," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"That's what the Tinkers told us," Perrin said.

"jɛs," ɛɡwin sɛd, "ði il stɔɹi."

"Yes," Egwene said, "the Aiel story."

mɔɪɹeɪn tɝn əɹ hɛd sloʊli. noʊ ʌðɝ pɑɹɾ ə hɝ muvd. "wʌt stɔɹi?"

Moiraine turned her head slowly. No other part of her moved. "What story?"

ɪt wɑz ən ɪkspɹɛʃənləs lʊk ʃi ɡeɪv ðɛm, bʌɾ ɪt meɪd pɛɹɪn teɪk ə dip bɹɛθ, ðoʊ wən i spoʊk i wɑz əz dɪlɪbɝɪɾ əz ɛvɝ. "sʌm tɪŋkɝz kɹɔsɪŋ ðə weɪst - ðeɪ sɛd ðeɪ kəd də ðəɾ ənhɑɹmd - faʊn il daɪɪŋ æftɝ ə bæɾəl wɪð tʃɹɑləks. bɪfɔɹ ðə læst il daɪd, ʃi - ðeɪ wɝ ɔl wɪmən, əpɛɹənli - toʊl ðə tɪŋkɝz wʌt lɔɪəl dʒʌst sɛd. ðə dɑɹk wʌn - ðeɪ kɔld ɪm saɪtblɪndɝ - ɪntɛnz tə blaɪn ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld. ðɪs wɑz oʊnli θɹi jɪɹz əɡoʊ, nɑt twɛnti. dʌz ɪt min sʌmθɪŋ?"

It was an expressionless look she gave them, but it made Perrin take a deep breath, though when he spoke he was as deliberate as ever. "Some Tinkers crossing the Waste - they said they could do that unharmed - found Aiel dying after a battle with Trollocs. Before the last Aiel died, she - they were all women, apparently - told the Tinkers what Loial just said. The Dark One - they called him Sightblinder - intends to blind the Eye of the World. This was only three years ago, not twenty. Does it mean something?"

"pɝhæps ɛvɹiθɪŋ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. hɝ feɪs wɑz stɪl, bʌt ɹænd hæd ðə filɪŋ əɹ maɪn ɹeɪs bɪhaɪn ðoʊz dɑɹk aɪz.

"Perhaps everything," Moiraine said. Her face was still, but Rand had the feeling her mind raced behind those dark eyes.

"bælzəmən," pɛɹɪn sɛd sʌɾənli. ðə neɪm kʌɾ ɔf ɔl saʊn ɪn ðə ɹum. noʊ wʌn əpɪɹd tə bɹið. pɛɹɪn lʊkt ət ɹænd, ðən ət mæt, hɪz aɪz stʃɹeɪnʒli kɑm ən mɔɹ jɛloʊ ðən ɛvɝ. "æt ðə taɪm aɪ wʌndɝd wɛɹ aɪd hɝd ðət neɪm bɪfɔɹ . . . ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld. naʊ aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ. doʊn ju?"

"Ba'alzamon," Perrin said suddenly. The name cut off all sound in the room. No one appeared to breathe. Perrin looked at Rand, then at Mat, his eyes strangely calm and more yellow than ever. "At the time I wondered where I'd heard that name before . . . the Eye of the World. Now I remember. Don't you?"

"aɪ doʊnt wɑnə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛniθɪŋ," mæt sɛd stɪfli.

"I don't want to remember anything," Mat said stiffly.

"wi hæv tə tɛl hɝ," pɛɹɪn kəntɪnjud. "ɪts ɪmpɔɹɾənt naʊ. wi kæn kip ɪt sikɹəɾ ɛni lɔŋɡɝ. jə si ɪt, doʊn ju, ɹænd?"

"We have to tell her," Perrin continued. "It's important now. We can't keep it secret any longer. You see it, don't you, Rand?"

"tɛl mi wʌt?" mɔɪɹeɪnz vɔɪs wɑz hɑɹʃ, ən ʃi sim tə bi bɹeɪsɪŋ fəɹ ə bloʊ. hɝ ɡeɪz hæd sɛɾəld ɑn ɹænd.

"Tell me what?" Moiraine's voice was harsh, and she seemed to be bracing for a blow. Her gaze had settled on Rand.

hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ænsɝ. hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛni mɔɹ ðən mæt, bʌɾ i dɪd ɹɪmɛmbɝ - ən i nu pɛɹɪn wɑz ɹaɪt. "aɪv. . . ." hi lʊkt əɾ ɪz fɹɛnz. mæt nɑɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli, pɛɹɪn dɪsaɪsɪvli, bʌɾ ət lis ðeɪ hæd dʌn ɪt. hi dɪd nɑɾ əv tə feɪs əɹ əloʊn. "wi hæv hæd . . . dʒɹimz." hi ɹʌb ðə spɑɾ ɑn ɪz fɪŋɡɝ wɛɹ ðə θɔɹn hæd stʌk ɪm wʌns, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðə blʌd wən i woʊk. kwizəli ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðə sʌnbɝn fil ə hɪz feɪs ənʌðɝ taɪm. "ɪksɛp meɪbi ðeɪ wɝn dʒɹimz, ɪɡzækli. bælzəmən wɑz ɪn ðɛm." hi nu waɪ pɛɹɪn hæd juz ðət neɪm; ɪt wɑz iziɝ ðən seɪɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn hæd bɪn ɪn jəɹ dʒɹimz, ɪnsaɪd jəɹ hɛd. "hi sɛd . . . hi sɛɾ ɔl sɔɹts ə θɪŋz, bʌt wʌns i sɛd ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld wəd nɛvɝ sɝv mi." fəɹ ə mɪnuɾ ɪz maʊθ wɑz əz dʒɹaɪ əz dʌst.

He did not want to answer. He did not want to remember any more than Mat, but he did remember - and he knew Perrin was right. "I've. . . ." He looked at his friends. Mat nodded reluctantly, Perrin decisively, but at least they had done it. He did not have to face her alone. "We have had . . . dreams." He rubbed the spot on his finger where the thorn had stuck him once, remembering the blood when he woke. Queasily remembering the sunburned feel of his face another time. "Except maybe they weren't dreams, exactly. Ba'alzamon was in them." He knew why Perrin had used that name; it was easier than saying the Dark One had been in your dreams, inside your head. "He said . . . he said all sorts of things, but once he said the Eye of the World would never serve me." For a minute his mouth was as dry as dust.

"hi toʊl mi ðə seɪm θɪŋ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ən mæt saɪd hɛvəli, ðən nɑɾəd. ɹænd faʊn i hæd spɪɾ ɪn ɪz maʊθ əɡɛn. "ju ɑɹən æŋɡɹi wɪð ʌs?" pɛɹɪn æskt, saʊndɪŋ sɝpɹaɪzd, ən ɹænd ɹilaɪz ðət mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd nɑt sim æŋɡɹi. ʃi wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ ðɛm, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz wɝ klɪɹ ən kɑm, ɪf ɪntɛnt.

"He told me the same thing," Perrin said, and Mat sighed heavily, then nodded. Rand found he had spit in his mouth again. "You aren't angry with us?" Perrin asked, sounding surprised, and Rand realized that Moiraine did not seem angry. She was studying them, but her eyes were clear and calm, if intent.

"mɔɹ wɪð maɪsɛlf ðən ju. bʌɾ aɪ dɪɾ æsk jə tə tɛl mi ɪf jə hæd stʃɹeɪnʒ dʒɹimz. ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, aɪ æskt." ðoʊ hɝ vɔɪs ɹɪmeɪn lɛvəl, ə flæʃ ʌv æŋɡɝ kɹɔst əɹ aɪz, ən wɑz ɡɔn ɪn ən ɪnstənt. "hæɾ aɪ noʊn æftɝ ðə fɝst sʌtʃ, aɪ maɪɾ əv bɪn eɪbəl tə. . . . ðəɹ əz nɑt bɪn ə dʒɹimwɔkɝ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn fəɹ nɪɹli ə θaʊzən jɪɹz, bʌɾ aɪ kəɾ əv tʃɹaɪd. naʊ ɪts tu leɪt. itʃ taɪm ðə dɑɹk wʌn tʌtʃəz ju, hi meɪks ðə nɛks tʌtʃɪŋ iziɝ fəɹ hɪm. pɝhæps maɪ pɹɛzəns kən stɪl ʃil jə sʌmwʌt, bʌɾ ivən ðɛn. . . . ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə stɔɹiz ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən baɪndɪŋ mɛn tə ðɛm? stʃɹɔŋ mɛn, mɛn u hæd fɔt ðə dɑɹk wʌn fɹəm ðə stɑɹt. ðoʊz stɔɹiz ɑɹ tʃɹu, ən nʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən hæɾ ə tɛnθ ə ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə ðɛɹ mæstɝ, nɑɾ eɪdʒɪnɝ əɹ lænfɝ, nɑt bælθəməl əɹ dɪmɑndɝd, nɑɾ ivən ɪʃəml, ðə bɪtʃɹeɪɝ ə hoʊp hɪmsɛlf."

"More with myself than you. But I did ask you to tell me if you had strange dreams. In the beginning, I asked." Though her voice remained level, a flash of anger crossed her eyes, and was gone in an instant. "Had I known after the first such, I might have been able to. . . . There has not been a Dreamwalker in Tar Valon for nearly a thousand years, but I could have tried. Now it is too late. Each time the Dark One touches you, he makes the next touching easier for him. Perhaps my presence can still shield you somewhat, but even then. . . . Remember the stories of the Forsaken binding men to them? Strong men, men who had fought the Dark One from the start. Those stories are true, and none of the Forsaken had a tenth of the strength of their master, not Aginor or Lanfear, not Balthamel or Demandred, not even Ishamael, the Betrayer of Hope himself."

nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin wɝ lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ɹænd sɔ, hɪm ən mæt ən pɛɹɪn ɔl θɹi. ðə wɪmənz feɪsəz wɝ ə blʌd-dʒɹeɪn blɛn ə fɪɹ ən hɔɹɝ. ɑɹ ðeɪ əfɹeɪd fəɹ ʌs, əɹ əfɹeɪɾ ʌv ʌs?

Nynaeve and Egwene were looking at him, Rand saw, him and Mat and Perrin all three. The women's faces were a blood-drained blend of fear and horror. Are they afraid for us, or afraid of us?

"wʌt kən wi du?" hi æskt. "ðɛɹ əz tə bi sʌmθɪŋ."

"What can we do?" he asked. "There has to be something."

"steɪɪŋ kloʊs baɪ mi," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd, "wɪl hɛlp. sʌm. ðə pɹətɛkʃən fɹəm tʌtʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ɪkstɛnz ɝaʊn mi ə lɪɾəl, ɹɪmɛmbɝ. bʌt jə kænɑɾ ɔlweɪz ɹɪmeɪn kloʊs tə mi. jə kən dɪfɛn jɝsɛlf, ɪf juv ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ fəɹ ɪt, bʌt jə mʌs faɪn ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ən wɪl wɪðɪn jɝsɛlf. aɪ kænɑt ɡɪv ɪt tə ju."

"Staying close by me," Moiraine replied, "will help. Some. The protection from touching the True Source extends around me a little, remember. But you cannot always remain close to me. You can defend yourself, if you have the strength for it, but you must find the strength and will within yourself. I cannot give it to you."

"aɪ θɪŋk aɪv ɔlɹɛɾi faʊn maɪ pɹətɛkʃən," pɛɹɪn sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ɹɪzaɪn ɹæðɝ ðən hæpi.

"I think I've already found my protection," Perrin said, sounding resigned rather than happy.

"jɛs," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "aɪ səpoʊz jə hæv." ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɪm əntɪl i dʒɹɑpt ɪz aɪz, ən ivən ðən ʃi stʊd kənsɪɾɝɪŋ. faɪnəli ʃi tɝn tə ði ʌðɝz. "ðɛɹ ɑɹ lɪməts tə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz paʊɝ ɪnsaɪd ju. jild ivən fəɹ ən ɪnstən ən hɪl əv ə stʃɹɪŋ taɪd tə jəɹ hɑɹt, ə stʃɹɪŋ jə meɪ nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə kʌt. sɝɛndɝ, ən jəl bi hɪz. dɪnaɪ hɪm, ən ɪz paʊɝ feɪlz. ɪts nɑɾ izi wən i tʌtʃəz jəɹ dʒɹimz, bʌɾ ɪt kən bi dʌn. hi kən stɪl sɛn hæfmən əɡɛns ju, ən tʃɹɑləks, ən dʒɹæɡkɝ, ən ʌðɝ θɪŋz, bʌɾ i kænɑt meɪk jə hɪz ənlɛs jə lɛt hɪm."

"Yes," Moiraine said, "I suppose you have." She looked at him until he dropped his eyes, and even then she stood considering. Finally she turned to the others. "There are limits to the Dark One's power inside you. Yield even for an instant and he will have a string tied to your heart, a string you may never be able to cut. Surrender, and you will be his. Deny him, and his power fails. It is not easy when he touches your dreams, but it can be done. He can still send Halfmen against you, and Trollocs, and Draghkar, and other things, but he cannot make you his unless you let him."

"feɪdz ɑɹ bæɾ ɪnʌf," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Fades are bad enough," Perrin said.

"aɪ doʊnt wɑn ɪm ɪnsaɪd maɪ hɛɾ əɡɛn," mæt ɡɹaʊld. "ɪzən ðəɹ ɛni weɪ tə kip ɪm aʊt?"

"I don't want him inside my head again," Mat growled. "Isn't there any way to keep him out?"

mɔɪɹeɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "lɔɪəl əz nʌθɪŋ tə fɪɹ, nɔɹ ɛɡwin, nɔɹ nɪneɪiv. aʊɾ ə ðə mæs ə hjumænɪɾi, ðə dɑɹk wʌn kən tʌtʃ ən ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl oʊnli baɪ tʃæns, ənlɛs ðət pɝsən siks ɪt. bʌt fəɹ ə taɪm, ət list, jə θɹi ɑɹ sɛntʃɹəl tə ðə pæɾɝn. eɪ wɛb ə dɛstəni ɪz biɪŋ woʊvən, ən ɛvɹi θɹɛd lidz stʃɹeɪt tə ju. wʌɾ ɛls dɪd ðə dɑɹk wʌn seɪ tə ju?"

Moiraine shook her head. "Loial has nothing to fear, nor Egwene, nor Nynaeve. Out of the mass of humanity, the Dark One can touch an individual only by chance, unless that person seeks it. But for a time, at least, you three are central to the Pattern. A Web of Destiny is being woven, and every thread leads straight to you. What else did the Dark One say to you?"

"aɪ doʊn ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪɾ ɔl ðət wɛl," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðɛɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt wʌn ʌv əs biɪŋ tʃoʊzən, sʌmθɪŋ laɪk ðæt. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪm læfɪŋ," hi fɪnɪʃt blikli, "əbaʊɾ u wi wɝ tʃoʊzən baɪ. hi sɛɾ aɪ - wi kəd sɝv ɪm əɹ daɪ. ən ðən wid stɪl sɝv hɪm."

"I don't remember it all that well," Perrin said. "There was something about one of us being chosen, something like that. I remember him laughing," he finished bleakly, "about who we were chosen by. He said I - we could serve him or die. And then we'd still serve him."

"hi sɛd ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wəd tʃɹaɪ tə juz ʌs," mæt æɾəd, hɪz vɔɪs feɪɾɪŋ əz i ɹɪmɛmbɝd tə hum i wɑz spikɪŋ. hi swɑloʊɾ ən wɛn ɑn. "hi sɛd dʒʌs laɪk tɑɹ vəlɑn juzd - hi hæd səm neɪmz. dɑviən, aɪ θɪŋk. aɪ kæn ɹɪmɛmbɝ vɛɹi wɛl, iðɝ."

"He said the Amyrlin Seat would try to use us," Mat added, his voice fading as he remembered to whom he was speaking. He swallowed and went on. "He said just like Tar Valon used - he had some names. Davian, I think. I can't remember very well, either."

"ɹɑoʊlɪn dɑɹksbeɪn," pɛɹɪn sɛd.

"Raolin Darksbane," Perrin said.

"jɛs," ɹænd sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. hi hæd tʃɹaɪd tə fɝɡɛɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ əbaʊt ðoʊz dʒɹimz. ɪt wɑz ənplɛzən bɹɪŋɪŋ əm bæk. "jʊɹiən stoʊnboʊ wɑz ənʌðɝ, ən ɡɛɹ əmɑlɑsən." hi stɑp sʌɾənli, hoʊpɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn hæd nɑt noʊɾəst haʊ sʌɾənli. "aɪ doʊn ɹɛkəɡnaɪz ɛni ʌv ðɛm."

"Yes," Rand said, frowning. He had tried to forget everything about those dreams. It was unpleasant bringing them back. "Yurian Stonebow was another, and Guaire Amalasan." He stopped suddenly, hoping Moiraine had not noticed how suddenly. "I don't recognize any of them."

bʌɾ i hæd ɹɛkəɡnaɪzd wʌn, naʊ ðəɾ i dʒɹɛdʒd əm fɹəm ðə dɛpθs ə mɛmɹi. ðə neɪm i hæd bɛɹli stɑp hɪmsɛlf fɹəm seɪɪŋ. lɑɡən. ðə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. laɪt! tɑm sɛd ðeɪ wɝ deɪnʒɝəs neɪmz. ɪz ðət wʌt bælzəmən mɛnt? mɔɪɹeɪn wɑns tə juz wʌn ʌv əs əz ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən? ɛɛs sədaɪ hʌn daʊn fɔls dʒɹæɡənz, ðeɪ doʊn juz ðɛm. də ðeɪ? laɪt hɛlp mi, də ðeɪ?

But he had recognized one, now that he dredged them from the depths of memory. The name he had barely stopped himself from saying. Logain. The false Dragon. Light! Thom said they were dangerous names. Is that what Ba'alzamon meant? Moiraine wants to use one of us as a false Dragon? Aes Sedai hunt down false Dragons, they don't use them. Do they? Light help me, do they?

mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt ɹɛɾ əɹ feɪs. "du jə noʊ ðɛm?" hi æsk hɝ. "du ðeɪ min ɛniθɪŋ?"

Moiraine was looking at him, but he could not read her face. "Do you know them?" he asked her. "Do they mean anything?"

"ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz ɪz ə ɡʊd neɪm fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz ɪz weɪ tə sid ðə wɝm ə daʊt wɛɹɛvɝ i kʊd. ɪɾ its ət mɛnz maɪnz laɪk ə kæŋkɝ. wən jə bɪliv ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz, ɪts ðə fɝst stɛp təwɔɹd sɝɛndɝ. ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ɪf jə sɝɛndɝ tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, hɪl meɪk jə hɪz."

"The Father of Lies is a good name for the Dark One," Moiraine replied. "It was always his way to seed the worm of doubt wherever he could. It eats at men's minds like a canker. When you believe the Father of Lies, it is the first step toward surrender. Remember, if you surrender to the Dark One, he will make you his."

ən ɛɛs sədaɪ nɛvɝ laɪz, bʌt ðə tʃɹuθ ʃi spiks meɪ nɑt bi ðə tʃɹuθ jə θɪŋk jə hɪɹ. ðət wɑz wʌt tæm hæd sɛd, ən ʃi hæd nɑt ɹɪli ænsɝɾ ɪz kwɛstʃən. hi kɛpt ɪz feɪs ɪkspɹɛʃənləs ən hɛld ɪz hænz stɪl ɑn ɪz niz, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə skɹʌb ðə swɛɾ ɔf əm ɑn ɪz bɹitʃɪz.

An Aes Sedai never lies, but the truth she speaks may not be the truth you think you hear. That was what Tam had said, and she had not really answered his question. He kept his face expressionless and held his hands still on his knees, trying not to scrub the sweat off them on his breeches.

ɛɡwin wɑz kɹaɪɪŋ sɔfli. nɪneɪiv hæɾ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝ, bʌt ʃi lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə kɹaɪ, tu. ɹænd ɔlmoʊst wɪʃt i kʊd.

Egwene was crying softly. Nynaeve had her arms around her, but she looked as if she wanted to cry, too. Rand almost wished he could.

"ðeɪ ɑɹ ɔl tɑvɝən," lɔɪəl sɛɾ əbɹʌpli. hi sim bɹaɪɾənd baɪ ðə pɹɑspɛkt, lʊkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd tə wɑtʃɪŋ fɹəm kloʊs baɪ əz ðə pæɾɝn woʊv ɪtsɛlf ɝaʊn ðɛm. ɹænd lʊkt əɾ ɪm ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli, ən ði oʊɡiɝ ɡeɪv ən əbæʃt ʃɹʌɡ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɪnʌf tə dɪm ɪz iɡɝnəs.

"They are all ta'veren," Loial said abruptly. He seemed brightened by the prospect, looking forward to watching from close by as the Pattern wove itself around them. Rand looked at him incredulously, and the Ogier gave an abashed shrug, but it was not enough to dim his eagerness.

"soʊ ðeɪ ɑɹ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "θɹi ʌv ðɛm, wən aɪ ɪkspɛktəd wʌn. ə ɡɹeɪt mɛni θɪŋz əv hæpən ðəɾ aɪ dɪd nɑɾ ɪkspɛkt. ðɪs nuz kənsɝnɪŋ ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝl tʃeɪnʒəz mʌtʃ." ʃi pɔzd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. "fɔɹ ə taɪm ðə pæɾɝn dʌz sim tə bi swɝlɪŋ ɝaʊn ɔl θɹi ʌv ju, dʒʌst əz lɔɪəl sɛz, ən ðə swɝl wɪl ɡɹoʊ ɡɹeɪɾɝ bɪfɔɹ ɪt bɪkʌmz lɛs. səmtaɪmz biɪŋ tɑvɝən minz ðə pæɾɝn ɪz fɔɹs tə bɛn tə ju, ən səmtaɪmz ɪt minz ðə pæɾɝn fɔɹsɪz jə tə ðə niɾəd pæθ. ðə wɛb kən stɪl bi woʊvən mɛni weɪz, ən səm ə ðoʊz dɪzaɪnz wəd bi dɪzæstʃɹəs. fəɹ ju, fəɹ ðə wɝld.

"So they are," Moiraine said. "Three of them, when I expected one. A great many things have happened that I did not expect. This news concerning the Eye of the World changes much." She paused, frowning. "For a time the Pattern does seem to be swirling around all three of you, just as Loial says, and the swirl will grow greater before it becomes less. Sometimes being ta'veren means the Pattern is forced to bend to you, and sometimes it means the Pattern forces you to the needed path. The Web can still be woven many ways, and some of those designs would be disastrous. For you, for the world.

"wi kænɑt ɹɪmeɪn ɪn keɪɛmlɪn, bʌt baɪ ɛni ɹoʊd, mɹdʒɹɑl ən tʃɹɑləks wɪl bi ɑn əs bɪfɔɹ wɪv ɡɔn tɛn maɪlz. ən dʒʌst ət ðɪs pɔɪnt wi hɪɹ ʌv ə θɹɛt tə ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld, nɑt fɹəm wʌn sɔɹs, bʌt θɹi, itʃ simɪŋ ɪndɪpɛndən ə ði ʌðɝz. ðə pæɾɝn ɪz fɔɹsɪŋ əɹ pæθ. ðə pæɾɝn stɪl wivz ɪtsɛlf ɝaʊn jə θɹi, bʌt wʌt hænd naʊ sɛts ðə wɔɹp, ən wʌt hæn kəntʃɹoʊlz ðə ʃʌɾəl? hæz ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən wikən ɪnʌf fəɹ ɪm tə ɪɡzɝt ðət mʌtʃ kəntʃɹoʊl?"

"We cannot remain in Caemlyn, but by any road, Myrddraal and Trollocs will be on us before we have gone ten miles. And just at this point we hear of a threat to the Eye of the World, not from one source, but three, each seeming independent of the others. The Pattern is forcing our path. The Pattern still weaves itself around you three, but what hand now sets the warp, and what hand controls the shuttle? Has the Dark One's prison weakened enough for him to exert that much control?"

"ðɛɹz noʊ nid fəɹ ðət kaɪndə tɔk!" nɪneɪiv sɛd ʃɑɹpli. "jul oʊnli fɹaɪɾən ðɛm."

"There's no need for that kind of talk!" Nynaeve said sharply. "You'll only frighten them."

"bʌt nɑt ju?" mɔɪɹeɪn æskt. "ɪt fɹaɪɾənz mi. wɛl, pɝhæps jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt. fɪɹ kænɑt bi əlaʊd tə əfɛkt əɹ kɔɹs. wɛðɝ ðɪs ɪz ə tʃɹæp əɹ ə taɪmli wɔɹnɪŋ, wi mʌs də wʌt wi mʌst, ən ðəɾ ɪz tə ɹitʃ ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝl kwɪkli. ðə ɡɹin mæn mʌs noʊ ʌv ðɪs θɹɛt."

"But not you?" Moiraine asked. "It frightens me. Well, perhaps you are right. Fear cannot be allowed to affect our course. Whether this is a trap or a timely warning, we must do what we must, and that is to reach the Eye of the World quickly. The Green Man must know of this threat."

ɹænd ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt. ðə ɡɹin mæn? ði ʌðɝz stɛɹd, tu, ɔl bʌt lɔɪəl, huz bɹɔd feɪs lʊkt wɝid.

Rand gave a start. The Green Man? The others stared, too, all but Loial, whose broad face looked worried.

"aɪ kænɑɾ ivən ɹɪsk stɑpɪŋ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn fəɹ hɛlp," mɔɪɹeɪn kəntɪnjud. "taɪm tʃɹæps ʌs. ivən ɪf wi kəd ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə sɪɾi ənhɪndɝd, ɪt wəd teɪk mɛni wiks tə ɹitʃ ðə blaɪt, ən aɪ fɪɹ wi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ əv wiks."

"I cannot even risk stopping in Tar Valon for help," Moiraine continued. "Time traps us. Even if we could ride out of the city unhindered, it would take many weeks to reach the Blight, and I fear we no longer have weeks."

"ðə blaɪt!" ɹænd hɝd hɪmsɛlf ɛkoʊɾ ɪn ə kɔɹəs, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn ɪɡnɔɹɾ əm ɔl.

"The Blight!" Rand heard himself echoed in a chorus, but Moiraine ignored them all.

"ðə pæɾɝn pɹizɛns ə kɹaɪsəs, ən ət ðə seɪm taɪm ə weɪ tə sɝmaʊn ɪt. ɪf aɪ dɪd nɑt noʊ ɪt wɑz ɪmpɑsəbəl, aɪ kəɾ ɔlmoʊs bɪliv ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ɪz teɪkɪŋ ə hænd. ðəɹ ɪz ə weɪ." ʃi smaɪld əz ɪf əɾ ə pɹaɪvət dʒoʊk, ən tɝn tə lɔɪəl. "ðɛɹ wɑz ən oʊɡiɝ ɡɹoʊv hɪɹ ət keɪɛmlɪn, ən ə weɪɡeɪt. ðə nu sɪɾi naʊ spɹɛdz aʊɾ oʊvɝ wɛɹ ðə ɡɹoʊv wʌns stʊd, soʊ ðə weɪɡeɪt mʌs bi ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz. aɪ noʊ nɑt mɛni oʊɡiɝ lɝn ðə weɪz naʊ, bʌt wʌn u hæz ə tælən ən lɝnz ði oʊl sɔŋz ʌv ɡɹoʊɪŋ mʌs bi dʒɹɔn tə sətʃ nɑlədʒ, ivən ɪf i bɪlivz ɪɾəl nɛvɝ bi juzd. dʒju noʊ ðə weɪz, lɔɪəl?"

"The Pattern presents a crisis, and at the same time a way to surmount it. If I did not know it was impossible, I could almost believe the Creator is taking a hand. There is a way." She smiled as if at a private joke, and turned to Loial. "There was an Ogier grove here at Caemlyn, and a Waygate. The New City now spreads out over where the grove once stood, so the Waygate must be inside the walls. I know not many Ogier learn the Ways now, but one who has a Talent and learns the old Songs of Growing must be drawn to such knowledge, even if he believes it will never be used. Do you know the Ways, Loial?"

ði oʊɡiɝ ʃɪftəɾ ɪz fiɾ ənizəli. "aɪ du, ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌt - "

The Ogier shifted his feet uneasily. "I do, Aes Sedai, but - "

"kæn jə faɪn ðə pæθ tə fæl dæɹə əlɔŋ ðə weɪz?"

"Can you find the path to Fal Dara along the Ways?"

"aɪv nɛvɝ hɝɾ ə fæl dæɹə," lɔɪəl sɛd, saʊndɪŋ ɹɪlivd.

"I've never heard of Fal Dara," Loial said, sounding relieved.

"ɪn ðə deɪz ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz ɪt wɑz noʊn əz mæfəl dɑɾɝɑnɛl. dʒju noʊ ðət neɪm?"

"In the days of the Trolloc Wars it was known as Mafal Dadaranell. Do you know that name?"

"aɪ noʊ ɪt," lɔɪəl sɛd ɹɪlʌktənli, "bʌt - "

"I know it," Loial said reluctantly, "but - "

"ðɛn jə kən faɪn ðə pæθ fəɹ ʌs," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ə kjʊɹiəs tɝn, ɪndid. wən wi kən niðɝ steɪ nɔɹ liv baɪ ɛni ɔɹɾənɛɹi minz, aɪ lɝn ʌv ə θɹɛt tə ði aɪ, ən ɪn ðə seɪm pleɪs ðəɹ ɪz wʌn u kən teɪk əs ðəɹ ɪn deɪz. wɛðɝ ɪts ðə kɹieɪɾɝ, əɹ feɪt, əɹ ivən ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ðə pæɾɝn əz tʃoʊzən əɹ pæθ fəɹ ʌs."

"Then you can find the path for us," Moiraine said. "A curious turn, indeed. When we can neither stay nor leave by any ordinary means, I learn of a threat to the Eye, and in the same place there is one who can take us there in days. Whether it is the Creator, or fate, or even the Dark One, the Pattern has chosen our path for us."

"noʊ!" lɔɪəl sɛd, ən ɛmfæɾɪk ɹʌmbəl laɪk θʌndɝ. ɛvɹiwʌn tɝn tə lʊk əɾ ɪm ən i blɪŋkt ʌndɝ ði ətɛnʃən, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ hɛzɪɾənt əbaʊɾ ɪz wɝdz. "ɪf wi ɛntɝ ðə weɪz, wɪl ɔl daɪ - əɹ bi swɑloʊd baɪ ðə ʃædoʊ."

"No!" Loial said, an emphatic rumble like thunder. Everyone turned to look at him and he blinked under the attention, but there was nothing hesitant about his words. "If we enter the Ways, we will all die - or be swallowed by the Shadow."


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾiθɹi


CHAPTER 43

dɪsɪʒənz ən æpɹɪʃənz


Decisions and Apparitions

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əpɪɹd tə noʊ wʌt lɔɪəl mɛnt, bʌt ʃi sɛd nʌθɪŋ. lɔɪəl pɪɹɾ ət ðə flɔɹ, ɹʌbɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz noʊz wɪð ə θɪk fɪŋɡɝ, əz ɪf i wɑz əbæʃt baɪ hɪz aʊtbɝst. noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə spik.

The Aes Sedai appeared to know what Loial meant, but she said nothing. Loial peered at the floor, rubbing under his nose with a thick finger, as if he was abashed by his outburst. No one wanted to speak.

"waɪ?" ɹænd æskt ət læst. "waɪ wəd wi daɪ? wʌɾ ɑɹ ðə weɪz?"

"Why?" Rand asked at last. "Why would we die? What are the Ways?"

lɔɪəl ɡlænst ət mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃi tɝn əweɪ tə teɪk ə tʃɛɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ðə lɪɾəl kæt stʃɹɛtʃt, ɪts klɔz skɹætʃɪŋ ɑn ðə hɑɹθstoʊn, ən læŋɡwdli wɔkt oʊvɝ tə bʌɾ ɪts hɛɾ əɡɛnst əɹ æŋkəlz. ʃi ɹʌbd bɪhaɪn ɪts ɪɹz wɪð wʌn fɪŋɡɝ. ðə kæts pɝɪŋ wɑz ə stʃɹeɪnʒ kaʊntɝpɔɪn tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪz lɛvəl vɔɪs. "ɪɾ ɪz jəɹ nɑlədʒ, lɔɪəl. ðə weɪz ɑɹ ði oʊnli pæθ tə seɪfti fəɹ ʌs, ði oʊnli pæθ tə fɔɹstɑlɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ɪf oʊnli fəɹ ə taɪm, bʌt ðə tɛlɪŋ ɪz jʊɹz."

Loial glanced at Moiraine. She turned away to take a chair in front of the fireplace. The little cat stretched, its claws scratching on the hearthstone, and languidly walked over to butt its head against her ankles. She rubbed behind its ears with one finger. The cat's purring was a strange counterpoint to the Aes Sedai's level voice. "It is your knowledge, Loial. The Ways are the only path to safety for us, the only path to forestalling the Dark One, if only for a time, but the telling is yours."

ði oʊɡiɝ dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ kʌmfɝɾɪd baɪ hɝ spitʃ. hi ʃɪftəɾ ɔkwɝdli ɑn ɪz tʃɛɹ bɪfɔɹ bɪɡɪnɪŋ. "dʊɹɪŋ ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, waɪl ðə wɝld wɑz stɪl biɪŋ bɹoʊkən, ði ɝθ wɑz ɪn əphivəl, ən hjumənkaɪnd wɑz biɪŋ skæɾɝd laɪk dʌst ɑn ðə wɪnd. wi oʊɡiɝ wɝ skæɾɝd, tu, dʒɹɪvən fɹəm ðə stɛɾɪŋ, ɪndə ði ɛɡzaɪl ən ðə lɔŋ wɑndɝɪŋ, wən ðə lɔŋɪŋ wɑz ɡɹeɪvən ɑn əɹ hɑɹts." hi ɡeɪv mɔɪɹeɪn ənʌðɝ saɪɾɛlɔŋ lʊk. hɪz lɔŋ aɪbɹaʊz dʒɹu daʊn ɪndə tu pɔɪns. "aɪ wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə bi bɹif, bʌt ðɪs ɪz nɑɾ ə θɪŋ ðət kən bi toʊl tu bɹifli. ɪts ə ði ʌðɝz aɪ mʌst spik, naʊ, ðoʊz fju oʊɡiɝ u hɛld ɪn ðɛɹ stɛɾɪŋ waɪl ɝaʊn əm ðə wɝld wɑz tɛɹɪŋ əpɑɹt. ən ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ" - hi əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət mɔɪɹeɪn, naʊ - "ðə meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ hu wɝ daɪɪŋ ivən əz ðeɪ dɪstʃɹɔɪd ðə wɝld ɪn ðɛɹ mædnəs. ɪt wɑz tə ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ - ðoʊz u hæd soʊ fɑɹ mænədʒ tə əvɔɪd ðə mædnəs - ðət ðə stɛɾɪŋ fɝs meɪd ði ɔfɝ ə sæŋktʃuɛɹi. mɛni æksɛptɪd, fəɹ ɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ ðeɪ wɝ pɹətɛktəd fɹəm ðə teɪn ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ðət wɑz kɪlɪŋ ðɛɹ kaɪnd. bʌt ðeɪ wɝ kʌɾ ɔf fɹəm ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. ɪt wɑz nɑt dʒʌs ðət ðeɪ kəd nɑt wil ðə wʌn paʊɝ, əɹ tʌtʃ ðə sɔɹs; ðeɪ kəd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ivən sɛns ðət ðə sɔɹs ɪɡzɪstəd. ɪn ði ɛnd, nʌn kəɾ æksɛp ðəɾ aɪsəleɪʃən, ən wʌn baɪ wʌn ðeɪ lɛf ðə stɛɾɪŋ, hoʊpɪŋ ðət baɪ ðət taɪm ðə teɪnt wɑz ɡɔn. ɪt nɛvɝ wɑz."

The Ogier did not appear comforted by her speech. He shifted awkwardly on his chair before beginning. "During the Time of Madness, while the world was still being broken, the earth was in upheaval, and humankind was being scattered like dust on the wind. We Ogier were scattered, too, driven from the stedding, into the Exile and the Long Wandering, when the Longing was graven on our hearts." He gave Moiraine another sidelong look. His long eyebrows drew down into two points. "I will try to be brief, but this is not a thing that can be told too briefly. It is of the others I must speak, now, those few Ogier who held in their stedding while around them the world was tearing apart. And of the Aes Sedai" - he avoided looking at Moiraine, now - "the male Aes Sedai who were dying even as they destroyed the world in their madness. It was to those Aes Sedai - those who had so far managed to avoid the madness - that the stedding first made the offer of sanctuary. Many accepted, for in the stedding they were protected from the taint of the Dark One that was killing their kind. But they were cut off from the True Source. It was not just that they could not wield the One Power, or touch the Source; they could no longer even sense that the Source existed. In the end, none could accept that isolation, and one by one they left the stedding, hoping that by that time the taint was gone. It never was."

"sʌm ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd kwaɪətli, "kleɪm ðəɾ oʊɡiɝ sæŋktʃuɛɹi pɹəlɔŋ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ən meɪɾ ɪt wɝs. ʌðɝz seɪ ðəɾ ɪf ɔl ə ðoʊz mɛn hæd bɪn əlaʊd tə ɡoʊ mæɾ ət wʌns, ðəɹ wʊɾə bɪn nʌθɪŋ lɛft ə ðə wɝld. aɪm ə ðə blu ədʒɑ, lɔɪəl; ənlaɪk ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, wi hoʊl tə ðə sɛkən vju. sæŋktʃuɛɹi hɛlp tə seɪv wʌt kəd bi seɪvd. kəntɪnju, pliz."

"Some in Tar Valon," Moiraine said quietly, "claim that Ogier sanctuary prolonged the Breaking and made it worse. Others say that if all of those men had been allowed to go mad at once, there would have been nothing left of the world. I am of the Blue Ajah, Loial; unlike the Red Ajah, we hold to the second view. Sanctuary helped to save what could be saved. Continue, please."

lɔɪəl nɑɾəd ɡɹeɪtfəli. ɹɪlivd ʌv ə kənsɝn, ɹænd ɹilaɪzd.

Loial nodded gratefully. Relieved of a concern, Rand realized.

"æz aɪ wɑz seɪɪŋ," ði oʊɡiɝ wɛn ɑn, "ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə meɪl sədaɪ, lɛft. bʌt bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɛnt, ðeɪ ɡeɪv ə ɡɪf tə ði oʊɡiɝ ɪn θæŋks fəɹ əɹ sæŋktʃuɛɹi. ðə weɪz. ɛntɝ ə weɪɡeɪt, wɔk fəɹ ə deɪ, ən jə meɪ dɪpɑɹt θɹu ənʌðɝ weɪɡeɪɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd maɪlz fɹəm wɛɹ jə stɑɹɾəd. əɹ faɪv hʌnʒɹəd. taɪm ən dɪstəns ɑɹ stʃɹeɪnʒ ɪn ðə weɪz. dɪfɹən pæðz, dɪfɹən bɹɪdʒəz, lɛd tə dɪfɹən pleɪsəz, ən haʊ lɔŋ ɪt teɪks tə ɡɛt ðəɹ dɪpɛnz ɑn wɪtʃ pæθ jə teɪk. ɪt wɑz ə mɑɹvələs ɡɪft, meɪd mɔɹ soʊ baɪ ðə taɪmz, fəɹ ðə weɪz ɑɹ nɑt pɑɹɾ ə ðə wɝld wi si ɝaʊn ʌs, nɔɹ pɝhæps ʌv ɛni wɝld aʊtsaɪd ðɛmsɛlvz. nɑɾ oʊnli dɪd ði oʊɡiɝ soʊ ɡɪftəd nɑɾ əv tə tʃɹævəl θɹu ðə wɝld, wɛɹ ivən æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ mɛn fɔt laɪk ænəməlz tə lɪv, ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ɹitʃ ənʌðɝ stɛɾɪŋ, bʌt wɪðɪn ðə weɪz ðəɹ wɑz noʊ bɹeɪkɪŋ. ðə læn bɪtwin tu stɛɾɪŋ maɪt splɪɾ oʊpən ɪndə dip kænjənz əɹ ɹaɪz ɪn maʊntən ɹeɪnʒəz, bʌɾ ɪn ðə weɪ bɪtwin əm ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃeɪnʒ.

"As I was saying," the Ogier went on, "the Aes Sedai, the male Sedai, left. But before they went, they gave a gift to the Ogier in thanks for our sanctuary. The Ways. Enter a Waygate, walk for a day, and you may depart through another Waygate a hundred miles from where you started. Or five hundred. Time and distance are strange in the Ways. Different paths, different bridges, lead to different places, and how long it takes to get there depends on which path you take. It was a marvelous gift, made more so by the times, for the Ways are not part of the world we see around us, nor perhaps of any world outside themselves. Not only did the Ogier so gifted not have to travel through the world, where even after the Breaking men fought like animals to live, in order to reach another stedding, but within the Ways there was no Breaking. The land between two stedding might split open into deep canyons or rise in mountain ranges, but in the Way between them there was no change.

"wɛn ðə læst ɛɛs sədaɪ lɛf ðə stɛɾɪŋ, ðeɪ ɡeɪv tə ði ɛldɝz ə ki, ə tælɪsmən, ðət kəd bi juz fəɹ ɡɹoʊɪŋ mɔɹ. ðeɪ ɑɹ ə lɪvɪŋ θɪŋ ɪn səm fæʃən, ðə weɪz ən ðə weɪɡeɪts. aɪ də nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn ɪt; noʊ oʊɡiɝ ɛvɝ hæz, ən ivən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ hæv fɝɡɑɾən, aɪm toʊld. oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz ði ɛɡzaɪl ɛndəd fəɹ ʌs. əz ðoʊz oʊɡiɝ u hæd bɪn ɡɪftəd baɪ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ faʊn ə stɛɾɪŋ wɛɹ oʊɡiɝ hæd ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðə lɔŋ wɑndɝɪŋ, ðeɪ ɡɹu ə weɪ tə ɪt. wɪð ðə stoʊnwɝk wi lɝn dʊɹɪŋ ði ɛɡzaɪl, wi bɪl sɪɾiz fəɹ mɛn, ən plæntəd ðə ɡɹoʊvz tə kʌmfɝt ði oʊɡiɝ u dɪd ðə bɪldɪŋ, soʊ ðə lɔŋɪŋ wəd nɑɾ oʊvɝkʌm ðɛm. tə ðoʊz ɡɹoʊvz weɪz wɝ ɡɹoʊn. ðəɹ wɑz ə ɡɹoʊv, ən ə weɪɡeɪt, ət mæfəl dɑɾɝɑnɛl, bʌt ðət sɪɾi wɑz ɹeɪz dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, noʊ stoʊn lɛf stændɪŋ ɑn ənʌðɝ, ən ðə ɡɹoʊv wɑz tʃɑp daʊn ən bɝn fəɹ tʃɹɑlɑk faɪɝz." hi lɛf noʊ daʊt wɪtʃ hæd bɪn ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ kɹaɪm.

"When the last Aes Sedai left the stedding, they gave to the Elders a key, a talisman, that could be used for growing more. They are a living thing in some fashion, the Ways and the Waygates. I do not understand it; no Ogier ever has, and even the Aes Sedai have forgotten, I am told. Over the years the Exile ended for us. As those Ogier who had been gifted by the Aes Sedai found a stedding where Ogier had returned from the Long Wandering, they grew a Way to it. With the stonework we learned during the Exile, we built cities for men, and planted the groves to comfort the Ogier who did the building, so the Longing would not overcome them. To those groves Ways were grown. There was a grove, and a Waygate, at Mafal Dadaranell, but that city was razed during the Trolloc Wars, no stone left standing on another, and the grove was chopped down and burned for Trolloc fires." He left no doubt which had been the greater crime.

"weɪɡeɪts ɑɹ ɔl bʌɾ ɪmpɑsəbəl tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "æn hjumənkaɪnd nɑt mʌtʃ lɛs soʊ. ðəɹ ɑɹ pipəl ət fæl dæɹə stɪl, ðoʊ nɑt ðə ɡɹeɪt sɪɾi ði oʊɡiɝ bɪlt, ən ðə weɪɡeɪt jɛt stænz."

"Waygates are all but impossible to destroy," Moiraine said, "and humankind not much less so. There are people at Fal Dara still, though not the great city the Ogier built, and the Waygate yet stands."

"haʊ dɪd ðeɪ meɪk ðɛm?" ɛɡwin æskt. hɝ pʌzəld lʊk tʊk ɪn mɔɪɹeɪn ən lɔɪəl boʊθ. "ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə mɛn. ɪf ðeɪ kʊdn juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ, haʊ kəd ðeɪ meɪk ðə weɪz? əɹ dɪd ðeɪ juz ðə paʊɝ əɾ ɔl? ðɛɹ pɑɹɾ ə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs wɑz teɪntɪd. ɪz teɪntɪd. aɪ doʊnt noʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt wʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ kən du, jɛt. meɪbi ɪts ə sɪli kwɛstʃən."

"How did they make them?" Egwene asked. Her puzzled look took in Moiraine and Loial both. "The Aes Sedai, the men. If they couldn't use the One Power in a stedding, how could they make the Ways? Or did they use the Power at all? Their part of the True Source was tainted. Is tainted. I don't know much about what Aes Sedai can do, yet. Maybe it's a silly question."
