lɔɪəl ɪkspleɪnd. "itʃ stɛɾɪŋ əz ə weɪɡeɪɾ ɑn ɪts bɔɹɾɝ, bʌɾ aʊtsaɪd. jəɹ kwɛstʃən ɪz nɑt sɪli. juv faʊn ðə siɾ ʌv waɪ wi də nɑt dɛɹ tʃɹævəl ðə weɪz. noʊ oʊɡiɝ əz juz ðə weɪz ɪn maɪ laɪftaɪm, ən bɪfɔɹ. baɪ iɾɪkt ə ði ɛldɝz, ɔl ði ɛldɝz ʌv ɔl ðə stɛɾɪŋ, nʌn meɪ, hjumən əɹ oʊɡiɝ.

Loial explained. "Each stedding has a Waygate on its border, but outside. Your question is not silly. You've found the seed of why we do not dare travel the Ways. No Ogier has used the Ways in my lifetime, and before. By edict of the Elders, all the Elders of all the stedding, none may, human or Ogier.

"ðə weɪz wɝ meɪd baɪ mɛn wildɪŋ paʊɝ faʊl baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. əbaʊɾ ə θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ, dʊɹɪŋ wʌt jə hjumənz kɔl ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ðə weɪz bɪɡæn tə tʃeɪnʒ. soʊ sloʊli ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ðət nʌn ɹɪli noʊɾəst, ðeɪ ɡɹu dæŋk ən dɪm. ðən dɑɹknəs fɛl əlɔŋ ðə bɹɪdʒəz. səm u wɛn ɪn wɝ nɛvɝ sin əɡɛn. tʃɹævəlɝz spoʊk ə biɪŋ wɑtʃt fɹəm ðə dɑɹk. ðə nʌmbɝz u vænɪʃt ɡɹu, ən səm u keɪm aʊt hæd ɡɔn mæd, ɹeɪvɪŋ əbaʊt mætʃɪn ʃɪn, ðə blæk wɪnd. ɛɛs sədaɪ hilɝz kəɾ eɪd sʌm, bʌɾ ivən wɪð ɛɛs sədaɪ hɛlp ðeɪ wɝ nɛvɝ ðə seɪm. ən ðeɪ nɛvɝ ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɛniθɪŋ ʌv wʌt hæɾ əkɝd. jɛɾ ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ðə dɑɹknəs hæd sʌŋkən ɪndə ðɛɹ boʊnz. ðeɪ nɛvɝ læft əɡɛn, ən ðeɪ fɪɹd ðə saʊn ə ðə wɪnd."

"The Ways were made by men wielding Power fouled by the Dark One. About a thousand years ago, during what you humans call the War of the Hundred Years, the Ways began to change. So slowly in the beginning that none really noticed, they grew dank and dim. Then darkness fell along the bridges. Some who went in were never seen again. Travelers spoke of being watched from the dark. The numbers who vanished grew, and some who came out had gone mad, raving about Machin Shin, the Black Wind. Aes Sedai Healers could aid some, but even with Aes Sedai help they were never the same. And they never remembered anything of what had occurred. Yet it was as if the darkness had sunken into their bones. They never laughed again, and they feared the sound of the wind."

fəɹ ə moʊmən ðəɹ wɑz saɪləns bʌt fəɹ ðə kæt pɝɪŋ bɪsaɪd mɔɪɹeɪnz tʃɛɹ, ən ðə snæp ən kɹækəl ə ðə faɪɝ, pɑpɪŋ aʊt spɑɹks. ðən nɪneɪiv bɝst aʊɾ æŋɡɹəli, "æn jə ɪkspɛkt əs tə fɑloʊ jə ɪndə ðæt? jə mʌs bi mæd!"

For a moment there was silence but for the cat purring beside Moiraine's chair, and the snap and crackle of the fire, popping out sparks. Then Nynaeve burst out angrily, "And you expect us to follow you into that? You must be mad!"

"wɪtʃ wəd jə tʃuz ɪnstɛd?" mɔɪɹeɪn æskt kwaɪətli. "ðə waɪtkloʊks wɪðɪn keɪɛmlɪn, əɹ ðə tʃɹɑləks wɪθaʊt? ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət maɪ pɹɛzəns ɪn ɪtsɛlf ɡɪvz səm pɹətɛkʃən fɹəm ðə dɑɹk wʌnz wɝks."

"Which would you choose instead?" Moiraine asked quietly. "The Whitecloaks within Caemlyn, or the Trollocs without? Remember that my presence in itself gives some protection from the Dark One's works."

nɪneɪiv sɛɾəld bæk wɪð ən ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd saɪ.

Nynaeve settled back with an exasperated sigh.

"ju stɪl əv nɑɾ ɪkspleɪn tə mi," lɔɪəl sɛd, "waɪ aɪ ʃəd bɹeɪk ði iɾɪkt ə ði ɛldɝz. ən aɪ hæv noʊ dɪzaɪɝ tə ɛntɝ ðə weɪz. mʌɾi əz ðeɪ ɔfən ɑɹ, ðə ɹoʊdz mɛn meɪk əv sɝv mi wɛl ɪnʌf sɪns aɪ lɛf stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ."

"You still have not explained to me," Loial said, "why I should break the edict of the Elders. And I have no desire to enter the Ways. Muddy as they often are, the roads men make have served me well enough since I left Stedding Shangtai."

"hjumənkaɪn ən oʊɡiɝ, ɛvɹiθɪŋ ðət laɪvz, wəɹ ət wɔɹ wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɑɹɾ ə ðə wɝl dʌz nɑɾ ivən noʊ ɪt jɛt, ən moʊst ə ðə fju hu də faɪt skɝmɪʃɪz ən bɪliv ðeɪ ɑɹ bæɾəlz. waɪl ðə wɝld ɹəfjuzəz tə bɪliv, ðə dɑɹk wʌn meɪ bi ət ðə bɹɪŋk ə vɪktɝi. ðəɹ ɪz ɪnʌf paʊɝ ɪn ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝl tə əndu hɪz pɹɪzən. ɪf ðə dɑɹk wʌn əz faʊn səm weɪ tə bɛn ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝl tə hɪz jus. . . ."

"Humankind and Ogier, everything that lives, we are at war with the Dark One," Moiraine said. "The greater part of the world does not even know it yet, and most of the few who do fight skirmishes and believe they are battles. While the world refuses to believe, the Dark One may be at the brink of victory. There is enough power in the Eye of the World to undo his prison. If the Dark One has found some way to bend the Eye of the World to his use. . . ."

ɹænd wɪʃt ðə læmps ɪn ðə ɹum wɝ lɪt. ivnɪŋ wɑz kɹipɪŋ oʊvɝ keɪɛmlɪn, ən ðə faɪɝ ɪn ðə faɪɝpleɪs dɪd nɑt ɡɪv ɪnʌf laɪt. hi wɑntəd noʊ ʃædoʊz ɪn ðə ɹum.

Rand wished the lamps in the room were lit. Evening was creeping over Caemlyn, and the fire in the fireplace did not give enough light. He wanted no shadows in the room.

"wʌt kən wi du?" mæt bɝst aʊt. "waɪ ɑɹ wi soʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt? waɪ də wɪv tə ɡoʊ tə ðə blaɪt? ðə blaɪt!"

"What can we do?" Mat burst out. "Why are we so important? Why do we have to go to the Blight? The Blight!"

mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd nɑt ɹeɪz əɹ vɔɪs, bʌɾ ɪt fɪl ðə ɹum, kəmpɛlɪŋ. hɝ tʃɛɹ baɪ ðə faɪɝ sʌɾənli sim laɪk ə θɹoʊn. sʌɾənli ivən mɔɹɡeɪs wʊɾə peɪld ɪn əɹ pɹɛzəns. "wʌn θɪŋ wi kən du. wi kən tʃɹaɪ. wʌt simz laɪk tʃæns ɪz ɔfən ðə pæɾɝn. θɹi θɹɛdz əv kʌm təɡɛðɝ hɪɹ, itʃ ɡɪvɪŋ ə wɔɹnɪŋ: ði aɪ. ɪt kænɑt bi tʃæns; ɪts ðə pæɾɝn. jə θɹi dɪd nɑt tʃuz; jə wɝ tʃoʊzən baɪ ðə pæɾɝn. ən jə ɑɹ hɪɹ, wɛɹ ðə deɪnʒɝ ɪz noʊn. jə kən stɛp əsaɪd, ən pɝhæps dum ðə wɝld. ɹʌnɪŋ, haɪɾɪŋ, wɪl nɑt seɪv jə fɹəm ðə wivɪŋ ə ðə pæɾɝn. əɹ jə kən tʃɹaɪ. jə kən ɡoʊ tə ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld, θɹi tɑvɝən, θɹi sɛntɝpɔɪns ə ðə wɛb, pleɪst wɛɹ ðə deɪnʒɝ laɪz. lɛt ðə pæɾɝn bi woʊvən ɝaʊn jə ðɛɹ, ən jə meɪ seɪv ðə wɝl fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊ. ðə tʃɔɪs ɪz jʊɹz. aɪ kænɑt meɪk jə ɡoʊ."

Moiraine did not raise her voice, but it filled the room, compelling. Her chair by the fire suddenly seemed like a throne. Suddenly even Morgase would have paled in her presence. "One thing we can do. We can try. What seems like chance is often the Pattern. Three threads have come together here, each giving a warning: the Eye. It cannot be chance; it is the Pattern. You three did not choose; you were chosen by the Pattern. And you are here, where the danger is known. You can step aside, and perhaps doom the world. Running, hiding, will not save you from the weaving of the Pattern. Or you can try. You can go to the Eye of the World, three ta'veren, three centerpoints of the Web, placed where the danger lies. Let the Pattern be woven around you there, and you may save the world from the Shadow. The choice is yours. I cannot make you go."

"aɪl ɡoʊ," ɹænd sɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə saʊn ɹɛzəlut. haʊɛvɝ hɑɹɾ i sɔt ðə vɔɪd, ɪmədʒəz kɛp flæʃɪŋ θɹu hɪz hɛd. tæm, ən ðə fɑɹmhaʊs, ən ðə flɑk ɪn ðə pæstʃɝ. ɪt hæd bɪn ə ɡʊd laɪf; hi hæd nɛvɝ ɹɪli wɑntəɾ ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ. ðəɹ wɑz kʌmfɝt - ə smɔl kʌmfɝt - hɪɹɪŋ pɛɹɪn ən mæt æd ðɛɹ əɡɹimən tə hɪz. ðeɪ saʊndəɾ əz dʒɹaɪ-maʊðd əz hi.

"I'll go," Rand said, trying to sound resolute. However hard he sought the void, images kept flashing through his head. Tam, and the farmhouse, and the flock in the pasture. It had been a good life; he had never really wanted anything more. There was comfort - a small comfort - hearing Perrin and Mat add their agreement to his. They sounded as dry-mouthed as he.

"aɪ səpoʊz ðəɹ ɪzən ɛni tʃɔɪs fəɹ ɛɡwin əɹ mi, iðɝ," nɪneɪiv sɛd.

"I suppose there isn't any choice for Egwene or me, either," Nynaeve said.

mɔɪɹeɪn nɑɾəd. "ju ɑɹ pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn, tu, boʊθ ə ju, ɪn səm fæʃən. pɝhæps nɑt tɑvɝən - pɝhæps - bʌt stʃɹɔŋ ivən soʊ. aɪ hæv noʊn ɪt sɪns bɛɹlən. ən noʊ daʊt baɪ ðɪs taɪm ðə feɪdz noʊ ɪt, tu. ən bælzəmən. jɛt juv əz mʌtʃ tʃɔɪs əz ðə jʌŋ mɛn. jə kəd ɹɪmeɪn hɪɹ, pɹoʊsid tə tɑɹ vəlɑn wʌns ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs əv ɡɔn."

Moiraine nodded. "You are part of the Pattern, too, both of you, in some fashion. Perhaps not ta'veren - perhaps - but strong even so. I have known it since Baerlon. And no doubt by this time the Fades know it, too. And Ba'alzamon. Yet you have as much choice as the young men. You could remain here, proceed to Tar Valon once the rest of us have gone."

"steɪ bɪhaɪnd!" ɛɡwin ɪkskleɪmd. "lɛt ðə ɹɛst ə jə ɡoʊ ɔf ɪndə deɪnʒɝ waɪl wi haɪɾ ʌndɝ ðə kʌvɝz? aɪ woʊn də ɪt!" ʃi kɑt ði ɛɛs sədaɪz aɪ ən dʒɹu bæk ə lɪɾəl, bʌt nɑɾ ɔl ə hɝ dɪfaɪəns vænɪʃt. "aɪ woʊn də ɪt," ʃi mʌɾɝd stʌbɝnli.

"Stay behind!" Egwene exclaimed. "Let the rest of you go off into danger while we hide under the covers? I won't do it!" She caught the Aes Sedai's eye and drew back a little, but not all of her defiance vanished. "I won't do it," she muttered stubbornly.

"aɪ səpoʊz ðət minz boʊθ ʌv əs wɪl əkʌmpəni ju." nɪneɪiv saʊndəd ɹɪzaɪnd, bʌɾ əɹ aɪz flæʃt wən ʃi æɾəd, "ju stɪl nid maɪ ɝbz, ɛɛs sədaɪ, ənlɛs juv sʌɾənli ɡeɪn səm əbɪləɾi aɪ doʊnt noʊ əbaʊt." hɝ vɔɪs hɛld ə tʃælənʒ ɹænd dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn mɪɹli nɑɾəd ən tɝn tə ði oʊɡiɝ.

"I suppose that means both of us will accompany you." Nynaeve sounded resigned, but her eyes flashed when she added, "You still need my herbs, Aes Sedai, unless you've suddenly gained some ability I don't know about." Her voice held a challenge Rand did not understand, but Moiraine merely nodded and turned to the Ogier.

"wɛl, lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹən sʌn ə hɑlən?"

"Well, Loial, son of Arent son of Halan?"

lɔɪəl oʊpən ɪz maʊθ twaɪs, hɪz tʌftəɾ ɪɹz twɪtʃɪŋ, bɪfɔɹ i spoʊk. "jɛs, wɛl. ðə ɡɹin mæn. ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld. ðəɹ mɛnʃən ɪn ðə bʊks, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ɛni oʊɡiɝ əz æktʃəli  sin əm ɪn, oʊ, kwaɪɾ ə lɔŋ taɪm. aɪ səpoʊz. . . . bʌt mʌst ɪt bi ðə weɪzmɔɪɹeɪn nɑɾəd, ən ɪz lɔŋ aɪbɹaʊz sæɡd tɪl ði ɛnz bɹʌʃt ɪz tʃiks. "vɛɹi wɛl, ðɛn. aɪ səpoʊz aɪ mʌst ɡaɪd ju. ɛldɝ heɪmən wəd seɪ ɪts noʊ lɛs ðən aɪ dɪzɝv fəɹ biɪŋ soʊ heɪsti ɔl ðə taɪm."

Loial opened his mouth twice, his tufted ears twitching, before he spoke. "Yes, well. The Green Man. The Eye of the World. They're mentioned in the books, of course, but I don't think any Ogier has actually seen them in, oh, quite a long time. I suppose. . . . But must it be the Ways?"Moiraine nodded, and his long eyebrows sagged till the ends brushed his cheeks. "Very well, then. I suppose I must guide you. Elder Haman would say it's no less than I deserve for being so hasty all the time."

"aʊɝ tʃɔɪsəz ɑɹ meɪd, ðɛn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ænd naʊ ðət ðeɪ ɑɹ meɪd, wi mʌs dɪsaɪd wʌt tə də əbaʊt ðɛm, ən haʊ."

"Our choices are made, then," Moiraine said. "And now that they are made, we must decide what to do about them, and how."

lɔŋ ɪndə ðə naɪt ðeɪ plænd. mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd moʊst ʌv ɪt, wɪð lɔɪəlz ædvaɪs kənsɝnɪŋ ðə weɪz, bʌt ʃi lɪsən tə kwɛstʃənz ən sədʒɛstʃənz fɹəm ɛvɹiwʌn. wʌns dɑɹk fɛl læn dʒɔɪn ðɛm, æɾɪŋ ɪz kɑmɛns ɪn ðəɾ aɪɝn-kɔɹd dʒɹɔl. nɪneɪiv meɪɾ ə lɪst ʌv wʌt səplaɪz ðeɪ niɾəd, dɪpɪŋ əɹ pɛn ɪn ði ɪŋkwɛl wɪð ə stɛɾi hæn dɪspaɪt ðə weɪ ʃi kɛp mʌɾɝɪŋ ʌndɝ əɹ bɹɛθ.

Long into the night they planned. Moiraine did most of it, with Loial's advice concerning the Ways, but she listened to questions and suggestions from everyone. Once dark fell Lan joined them, adding his comments in that iron-cored drawl. Nynaeve made a list of what supplies they needed, dipping her pen in the inkwell with a steady hand despite the way she kept muttering under her breath.

ɹænd wɪʃt i kəd bi əz mæɾɝ-ʌv-fækt əz ðə wɪzdəm. hi kəd nɑt stɑp peɪsɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn, əz ɪf i hæɾ ɛnɝdʒi tə bɝn əɹ bɝs fɹəm ɪt. hi nu hɪz dɪsɪʒən wɑz meɪd, nu ɪt wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn i kəd meɪk wɪð ðə nɑlədʒ i hæd, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt meɪk ɪm laɪk ɪt. ðə blaɪt. ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl wɑz sʌmwɛɹ ɪn ðə blaɪt, bɪɑn ðə blæstəd lænz.

Rand wished he could be as matter-of-fact as the Wisdom. He could not stop pacing up and down, as if he had energy to burn or burst from it. He knew his decision was made, knew it was the only one he could make with the knowledge he had, but that did not make him like it. The Blight. Shayol Ghul was somewhere in the Blight, beyond the Blasted Lands.

hi kəd si ðə seɪm wɝi ɪn mæts aɪz, ðə seɪm fɪɹ i nu wɑz ɪn ɪz oʊn. mæt sæt wɪð ɪz hænz klæspt, nʌkəlz waɪt. ɪf i lɛt ɡoʊ, ɹænd θɔt, hi wəd bi klʌtʃɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ɪnstɛd.

He could see the same worry in Mat's eyes, the same fear he knew was in his own. Mat sat with his hands clasped, knuckles white. If he let go, Rand thought, he would be clutching the dagger from Shadar Logoth instead.

ðəɹ wɑz noʊ wɝi ɑn pɛɹɪnz feɪs əɾ ɔl, bʌt wʌt wɑz ðəɹ wɑz wɝs: ə mæsk ʌv wɪɹi ɹɛzəɡneɪʃən. pɛɹɪn lʊkt əz ðoʊ hi hæd fɔt sʌmθɪŋ əntɪl i kəd faɪɾ ɪt noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ən wɑz weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪt tə fɪnɪʃ hɪm. jɛt səmtaɪmz. . . .

There was no worry on Perrin's face at all, but what was there was worse: a mask of weary resignation. Perrin looked as though he had fought something until he could fight it no longer and was waiting for it to finish him. Yet sometimes. . . .

"wi də wʌt wi mʌst, ɹænd," hi sɛd. "ðə blaɪt. . . ." fəɹ ən ɪnstən ðoʊz jɛloʊ aɪz lɪt wɪð iɡɝnəs, flæʃɪŋ ɪn ðə fɪks taɪɹədnəs ə hɪz feɪs, əz ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ə laɪf ə ðɛɹ oʊn əpɑɹt fɹəm ðə bɪɡ blæksmɪθs əpɹɛntəs. "ðɛɹz ɡʊd hʌntɪŋ əlɔŋ ðə blaɪt," hi wɪspɝd. ðən i ʃʌɾɝəd, əz ɪf i hæd dʒʌs hɝd wʌɾ i hæd sɛd, ən wʌns mɔɹ ɪz feɪs wɑz ɹɪzaɪnd.

"We do what we must, Rand," he said. "The Blight. . . ." For an instant those yellow eyes lit with eagerness, flashing in the fixed tiredness of his face, as if they had a life of their own apart from the big blacksmith's apprentice. "There's good hunting along the Blight," he whispered. Then he shuddered, as if he had just heard what he had said, and once more his face was resigned.

ən ɛɡwin. ɹænd dʒɹu hɝ əpɑɹɾ ət wʌn pɔɪnt, oʊvɝ baɪ ðə faɪɝpleɪs wɛɹ ðoʊz plænɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl kəd nɑt hɪɹ. "ɛɡwin, aɪ. . . ."hɝ aɪz, laɪk bɪɡ dɑɹk pulz dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪm ɪn, meɪɾ ɪm stɑp ən swɑloʊ. "ɪts mi ðə dɑɹk wʌnz æftɝ, ɛɡwin. meɪn, ən mæt, ən pɛɹɪn. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ wʌt mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛz. ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ jə ən nɪneɪiv kəd stɑɹt fəɹ hoʊm, əɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn, əɹ ɛniwɛɹ jə wɑnə ɡoʊ, ən noʊbɑdi wɪl tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp ju. nɑt ðə tʃɹɑləks, nɑt ðə feɪdz, nɑɾ ɛnibəɾi. əz lɔŋ əz jə ɑɹənt wɪð ʌs. ɡoʊ hoʊm, ɛɡwin. əɹ ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn. bʌt ɡoʊ."

And Egwene. Rand drew her apart at one point, over by the fireplace where those planning around the table could not hear. "Egwene, I. . . ."Her eyes, like big dark pools drawing him in, made him stop and swallow. "It's me the Dark One's after, Egwene. Me, and Mat, and Perrin. I don't care what Moiraine Sedai says. In the morning you and Nynaeve could start for home, or Tar Valon, or anywhere you want to go, and nobody will try to stop you. Not the Trollocs, not the Fades, not anybody. As long as you aren't with us. Go home, Egwene. Or go to Tar Valon. But go."

hi weɪɾəd fəɹ əɹ tə tɛl ɪm ʃi hæɾ əz mʌtʃ ɹaɪt tə ɡoʊ wɛɹ ʃi wɑntəɾ əz i dɪd, ðəɾ i hæd noʊ ɹaɪt tə tɛl əɹ wʌt tə du. tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz, ʃi smaɪld ən tʌtʃt ɪz tʃik.

He waited for her to tell him she had as much right to go where she wanted as he did, that he had no right to tell her what to do. To his surprise, she smiled and touched his cheek.

"θæŋk ju, ɹænd," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. hi blɪŋkt, ən kloʊzd ɪz maʊθ əz ʃi wɛn ɑn. "ju noʊ aɪ kænt, ðoʊ. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ toʊld əs wʌt mɪn sɔ, ɪn bɛɹlən. jə ʃʊɾə toʊl mi hu mɪn wɑz. aɪ θɔt. . . . wɛl, mɪn sɛz aɪm pɑɹɾ ə ðɪs, tu. ən nɪneɪiv. meɪbi aɪm nɑt tɑvɝən," ʃi stʌmbəld oʊvɝ ðə wɝd, "bʌt ðə pæɾɝn sɛnz mi tə ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld, tu, ɪt simz. wʌtɛvɝ ɪnvɑlvz ju, ɪnvɑlvz mi."

"Thank you, Rand," she said softly. He blinked, and closed his mouth as she went on. "You know I can't, though. Moiraine Sedai told us what Min saw, in Baerlon. You should have told me who Min was. I thought. . . . Well, Min says I am part of this, too. And Nynaeve. Maybe I'm not ta'veren," she stumbled over the word, "but the Pattern sends me to the Eye of the World, too, it seems. Whatever involves you, involves me."

"bʌt, ɛɡwin - "

"But, Egwene - "

"hu ɪz ɪleɪn?"

"Who is Elayne?"

fəɹ ə mɪnəɾ i stɛɹɾ ət hɝ, ðən toʊl ðə sɪmpəl tʃɹuθ. "ʃiz ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ tə ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ."

For a minute he stared at her, then told the simple truth. "She's the Daughter-Heir to the throne of Andor."

hɝ aɪz sim tə kætʃ faɪɝ. "ɪf jə kæn bi sɪɹiəs fəɹ mɔɹ ðən ə mɪnət, ɹænd ælθɹ, aɪ də nɑt wɑnə tɔk tə ju."

Her eyes seemed to catch fire. "If you can't be serious for more than a minute, Rand al'Thor, I do not want to talk to you."

ɪnkɹɛdʒələs, hi wɑtʃt əɹ stɪf bæk ɹɪtɝn tə ðə teɪbəl, wɛɹ ʃi lin ɑn əɹ ɛlboʊz nɛks tə mɔɪɹeɪn tə lɪsən tə wʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz seɪɪŋ. aɪ nid tə tɔk tə pɛɹɪn, hi θɔt. hi noʊz haʊ tə dil wɪð wɪmən.

Incredulous, he watched her stiff back return to the table, where she leaned on her elbows next to Moiraine to listen to what the Warder was saying. I need to talk to Perrin, he thought. He knows how to deal with women.

mæstɝ ɡɪl ɛntɝd sɛvɹəl taɪmz, fɝs tə laɪt ðə læmps, ðən tə bɹɪŋ fud wɪð ɪz oʊn hænz, ən leɪɾɝ tə ɹipɔɹɾ ɑn wʌt wɑz hæpənɪŋ aʊtsaɪd. waɪtkloʊks wɝ wɑtʃɪŋ ði ɪn fɹəm daʊn ðə stʃɹiɾ ɪn boʊθ dɝɛkʃənz. ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə ɹaɪəɾ ət ðə ɡeɪts tə ði ɪnɝ sɪɾi, wɪð ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz ɝɛstɪŋ waɪt kɑkeɪdz ən ɹɛɾ əlaɪk. sʌmwʌn hæd tʃɹaɪd tə skɹætʃ ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ ɑn ðə fɹʌn dɔɹ ən bɪn sɛn ɑn ɪz weɪ baɪ læmɡwɪnz but.

Master Gill entered several times, first to light the lamps, then to bring food with his own hands, and later to report on what was happening outside. Whitecloaks were watching the inn from down the street in both directions. There had been a riot at the gates to the Inner City, with the Queen's Guards arresting white cockades and red alike. Someone had tried to scratch the Dragon's Fang on the front door and been sent on his way by Lamgwin's boot.

ɪf ði ɪnkipɝ faʊn ɪɾ ɑd ðət lɔɪəl wɑz wɪð ðɛm, hi ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ʌv ɪt. hi ænsɝd ðə fju kwɛstʃənz mɔɪɹeɪn pʊt tə hɪm wɪθaʊt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dɪskʌvɝ wʌt ðeɪ wɝ plænɪŋ, ən itʃ taɪm i keɪm i nɑkt ət ðə dɔɹ ən weɪɾəd tɪl læn oʊpən ɪt fəɹ hɪm, dʒʌst əz ɪf ɪt wɝ nɑɾ ɪz ɪn ən ɪz laɪbɹɛɹi. ɑn ɪz læs vɪzət, mɔɪɹeɪn ɡeɪv ɪm ðə ʃiɾ ə pɑɹtʃmən kʌvɝɾ ɪn nɪneɪivz nit hænd.

If the innkeeper found it odd that Loial was with them, he gave no sign of it. He answered the few questions Moiraine put to him without trying to discover what they were planning, and each time he came he knocked at the door and waited till Lan opened it for him, just as if it were not his inn and his library. On his last visit, Moiraine gave him the sheet of parchment covered in Nynaeve's neat hand.

"ɪt woʊn bi izi ðɪs taɪm ə naɪt," hi sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ əz i pɝuz ðə lɪst, "bʌɾ əl ɝeɪnʒ ɪɾ ɔl."

"It won't be easy this time of night," he said, shaking his head as he perused the list, "but I'll arrange it all."

mɔɪɹeɪn æɾəd ə smɔl wɑʃ-lɛðɝ bæɡ ðət klɪŋkt əz ʃi hændəɾ ɪt tə hɪm baɪ ðə dʒɹɔstʃɹɪŋz. "ɡʊd. ən si ðət wəɹ wækən bɪfɔɹ deɪbɹeɪk. ðə wɑtʃɝz wɪl bi ət ðɛɹ list əlɝt, ðɛn."

Moiraine added a small wash-leather bag that clinked as she handed it to him by the drawstrings. "Good. And see that we are wakened before daybreak. The watchers will be at their least alert, then."

"wil liv əm wɑtʃɪŋ ən ɛmpti bɑks, ɛɛs sədaɪ." mæstɝ ɡɪl ɡɹɪnd.

"We'll leave them watching an empty box, Aes Sedai." Master Gill grinned.

ɹænd wɑz jɔnɪŋ baɪ ðə taɪm i ʃʌfəld aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum wɪð ðə ɹɛst ɪn sɝtʃ ə bæθs ən bɛdz. əz i skɹʌb hɪmsɛlf, wɪð ə kɔɹs klɔθ ɪn wʌn hæn ən ə bɪɡ jɛloʊ keɪk ə soʊp ɪn ði ʌðɝ, hɪz aɪz dʒɹɪftəd tə ðə stul bɪsaɪd mæts tʌb. ðə ɡoʊldən-ʃið tɪp ə ðə dæɡɝ fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ pik fɹəm ʌndɝ ði ɛdʒ ə mæts nitli foʊldəd koʊt. læn ɡlænst əɾ ɪt fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm, tu. ɹænd wʌndɝɾ ɪf ɪt wɑz ɹɪli əz seɪf tə hæv ɝaʊn əz mɔɪɹeɪn kleɪmd.

Rand was yawning by the time he shuffled out of the room with the rest in search of baths and beds. As he scrubbed himself, with a coarse cloth in one hand and a big yellow cake of soap in the other, his eyes drifted to the stool beside Mat's tub. The golden-sheathed tip of the dagger from Shadar Logoth peeked from under the edge of Mat's neatly folded coat. Lan glanced at it from time to time, too. Rand wondered if it was really as safe to have around as Moiraine claimed.

"du jə θɪŋk maɪ dɑl ɛvɝ bɪliv ɪt?" mæt læft, skɹʌbɪŋ ɪz bæk wɪð ə lɔŋ-hændəl bɹʌʃ. "mi, seɪvɪŋ ðə wɝld? maɪ sɪstɝz woʊnt noʊ wɛðɝ tə læf əɹ kɹaɪ."

"Do you think my da'll ever believe it?" Mat laughed, scrubbing his back with a long-handled brush. "Me, saving the world? My sisters won't know whether to laugh or cry."

hi saʊndəd laɪk ði oʊl mæt. ɹænd wɪʃt i kəd fɝɡɛt ðə dæɡɝ.

He sounded like the old Mat. Rand wished he could forget the dagger.

ɪt wɑz pɪtʃ-blæk wən i ən mæt faɪnəli ɡɑɾ ʌp tə ðɛɹ ɹum ʌndɝ ði ivz, ðə stɑɹz əbskjʊɹd baɪ klaʊdz. fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm ɪn ə lɔŋ waɪl mæt ənʒɹəst bɪfɔɹ ɡɛɾɪŋ ɪndə bɛd, bʌɾ i kæʒəwəli tʌk ðə dæɡɝ ʌndɝ ɪz pɪloʊ, tu. ɹænd blu aʊt ðə kændəl ən kɹɔld ɪndə hɪz oʊn bɛd. hi kəd fil ðə ɹɔŋɡnəs fɹəm ði ʌðɝ bɛd, nɑt fɹəm mæt, bʌt fɹəm bɪniθ ɪz pɪloʊ. hi wɑz stɪl wɝiɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt wən slip keɪm.

It was pitch-black when he and Mat finally got up to their room under the eaves, the stars obscured by clouds. For the first time in a long while Mat undressed before getting into bed, but he casually tucked the dagger under his pillow, too. Rand blew out the candle and crawled into his own bed. He could feel the wrongness from the other bed, not from Mat, but from beneath his pillow. He was still worrying about it when sleep came.

fɹəm ðə fɝst i nu ɪt wɑz ə dʒɹim, wʌn ə ðoʊz dʒɹimz ðət wɑz nɑɾ ɪntaɪɝli dʒɹim. hi stʊd stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə wʊɾən dɔɹ, ɪts sɝfəs dɑɹk ən kɹækt ən ɹʌf wɪð splɪntɝz. ði ɛɹ wɑz koʊld ən dæŋk, θɪk wɪð ðə smɛl ə dəkeɪ. ɪn ðə dɪstəns wɔɾɝ dʒɹɪpt, ðə splæʃəz hɑloʊ ɛkoʊz daʊn stoʊn kɔɹɪɾɝz.

From the first he knew it was a dream, one of those dreams that was not entirely dream. He stood staring at the wooden door, its surface dark and cracked and rough with splinters. The air was cold and dank, thick with the smell of decay. In the distance water dripped, the splashes hollow echoes down stone corridors.

dɪnaɪ ɪt. dɪnaɪ hɪm, ən ɪz paʊɝ feɪlz.

Deny it. Deny him, and his power fails.

hi kloʊzd ɪz aɪz ən kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ, ɑn ɪz bɛd, ɑn hɪmsɛlf əslip ɪn ɪz bɛd. wən i oʊpən ɪz aɪz ðə dɔɹ wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ. ði ɛkoʊɪŋ splæʃəz keɪm ɑn ɪz hɑɹtbit, əz ɪf ɪz pʌls kaʊntəd taɪm fəɹ ðɛm. hi sɔt ðə fleɪm ən ðə vɔɪd, əz tæm hæd tɔt hɪm, ən faʊn ɪnɝ kɑm, bʌt nʌθɪŋ aʊtsaɪɾ ə hɪm tʃeɪnʒd. sloʊli hi oʊpən ðə dɔɹ ən wɛn ɪn.

He closed his eyes and concentrated on The Queen's Blessing, on his bed, on himself asleep in his bed. When he opened his eyes the door was still there. The echoing splashes came on his heartbeat, as if his pulse counted time for them. He sought the flame and the void, as Tam had taught him, and found inner calm, but nothing outside of him changed. Slowly he opened the door and went in.

ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz əz i ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹum ðət sim bɝn aʊɾ ə ðə lɪvɪŋ ɹɑk. tɔl, ɑɹtʃt wɪndoʊz lɛɾ ɑntu ən ənɹeɪl bælkəni, ən bɪɑn ɪt ðə leɪɝd klaʊdz stʃɹim laɪk ə ɹɪvɝ ɪn flʌd. ðə blæk mɛɾəl læmps, ðɛɹ fleɪmz tu bɹaɪt tə lʊk æt, ɡlimd, blæk jɛt sʌmhaʊ əz bɹaɪɾ əz sɪlvɝ. ðə faɪɝ ɹɔɹd bʌt ɡeɪv noʊ hiɾ ɪn ðə fɪɹsəm faɪɝpleɪs, itʃ stoʊn stɪl veɪɡli laɪk ə feɪs ɪn tɔɹmɛnt.

Everything was as he remembered it in the room that seemed burned out of the living rock. Tall, arched windows led onto an unrailed balcony, and beyond it the layered clouds streamed like a river in flood. The black metal lamps, their flames too bright to look at, gleamed, black yet somehow as bright as silver. The fire roared but gave no heat in the fearsome fireplace, each stone still vaguely like a face in torment.

ɔl wɑz ðə seɪm, bʌt wʌn θɪŋ wɑz dɪfɹənt. ɑn ðə pɑlɪʃt teɪbəltɑp stʊd θɹi smɔl fɪɡjɝz, ðə ɹʌf, fitʃɝləs ʃeɪps ə mɛn, əz ɪf ðə skʌlptɝ hæd bɪn heɪsti wɪð ɪz kleɪ. bɪsaɪd wʌn stʊɾ ə wʊlf, ɪts klɪɹ dɪteɪl ɛmfəsaɪz baɪ ðə kɹudnəs ə ðə mæn-ʃeɪp, ən ənʌðɝ klʌtʃt ə taɪni dæɡɝ, ə pɔɪn ə ɹɛɾ ɑn ðə hɪlt ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ ɪn ðə laɪt. ðə læs hɛld ə sɔɹd. ðə hɛɹ stɝɪŋ ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk, hi muv kloʊs ɪnʌf tə si ðə hɛɹən ɪn ɛkskwəzət dɪteɪl ɑn ðət smɔl bleɪd.

All was the same, but one thing was different. On the polished tabletop stood three small figures, the rough, featureless shapes of men, as if the sculptor had been hasty with his clay. Beside one stood a wolf, its clear detail emphasized by the crudeness of the man-shape, and another clutched a tiny dagger, a point of red on the hilt glittering in the light. The last held a sword. The hair stirring on the back of his neck, he moved close enough to see the heron in exquisite detail on that small blade.

hɪz hɛd dʒɝkt ʌp ɪn pænɪk, ən i stɛɹd dɝɛkli ɪndə ðə loʊn mɪɹɝ. hɪz ɹəflɛkʃən wɑz stɪl ə blɝ, bʌt nɑt soʊ mɪsti əz bɪfɔɹ. hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊs meɪk aʊɾ ɪz oʊn fitʃɝz. ɪf i ɪmædʒən i wɑz skwɪntɪŋ, hi kəd nɪɹli tɛl u ɪt wɑz.

His head jerked up in panic, and he stared directly into the lone mirror. His reflection was still a blur, but not so misty as before. He could almost make out his own features. If he imagined he was squinting, he could nearly tell who it was.

"juv hɪɾən fɹəm mi tu lɔŋ."

"You've hidden from me too long."

hi wɝl fɹəm ðə teɪbəl, bɹɛθ ɹæspɪŋ ɪz θɹoʊt. ə moʊmən bɪfɔɹ i hæd bɪn əloʊn, bʌt naʊ bælzəmən stʊd bɪfɔɹ ðə wɪndoʊz. wən i spoʊk kævɝnz ə fleɪm ɹipleɪst ɪz aɪz ən maʊθ.

He whirled from the table, breath rasping his throat. A moment before he had been alone, but now Ba'alzamon stood before the windows. When he spoke caverns of flame replaced his eyes and mouth.

"tu lɔŋ, bʌt nɑt mʌtʃ lɔŋɡɝ."

"Too long, but not much longer."

"aɪ dɪnaɪ ju," ɹænd sɛd hɔɹsli. "aɪ dɪnaɪ ðət jə hoʊld ɛni paʊɝ oʊvɝ mi. aɪ dɪnaɪ ðət jə ɑɹ."

"I deny you," Rand said hoarsely. "I deny that you hold any power over me. I deny that you are."

bælzəmən læft, ə ɹɪtʃ saʊn ɹoʊlɪŋ fɹəm faɪɝ. "du jə θɪŋk ɪts ðəɾ izi? bʌt ðɛn, jə ɔlweɪz dɪd. itʃ taɪm wɪv stʊd laɪk ðɪs, juv θɔt jə kəd dɪfaɪ mi."

Ba'alzamon laughed, a rich sound rolling from fire. "Do you think it is that easy? But then, you always did. Each time we have stood like this, you have thought you could defy me."

"wʌt də min, itʃ taɪm? aɪ dɪnaɪ ju!"

"What do mean, each time? I deny you!"

"ju ɔlweɪz du. ɪn ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ðɪs kɑntɛs bɪtwin əs əz teɪkən pleɪs kaʊnləs taɪmz bɪfɔɹ. itʃ taɪm jəɹ feɪs ɪz dɪfɹənt, ən jəɹ neɪm, bʌɾ itʃ taɪm ɪts ju."

"You always do. In the beginning. This contest between us has taken place countless times before. Each time your face is different, and your name, but each time it is you."

"aɪ dɪnaɪ ju." ɪt wɑz ə dɛspɹɪt wɪspɝ.

"I deny you." It was a desperate whisper.

"itʃ taɪm jə θɹoʊ jəɹ pjuni stʃɹɛŋkθ əɡɛns mi, ən itʃ taɪm, ɪn ði ɛnd, jə noʊ wɪtʃ ʌv əs ɪz ðə mæstɝ. eɪdʒ æftɝ eɪdʒ, jə nil tə mi, əɹ daɪ wɪʃɪŋ jə stɪl hæd stʃɹɛŋkθ tə nil. pʊɹ ful, jə kən nɛvɝ wɪn əɡɛns mi."

"Each time you throw your puny strength against me, and each time, in the end, you know which of us is the master. Age after Age, you kneel to me, or die wishing you still had strength to kneel. Poor fool, you can never win against me."

"laɪɝ!" hi ʃaʊɾəd. "fɑðɝ ə laɪz. fɑðɝ ə fulz ɪf jə kæn də bɛɾɝ ðən ðæt. mɛn faʊn jə ɪn ðə læst eɪdʒ, ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ən baʊn jə bæk wɛɹ jə bɪlɔŋ."

"Liar!" he shouted. "Father of Lies. Father of Fools if you can't do better than that. Men found you in the last Age, in the Age of Legends, and bound you back where you belong."

bælzəmən læft əɡɛn, pil æftɝ mɑkɪŋ pil, əntɪl ɹænd wɑntəd tə kʌvɝ ɪz ɪɹz tə ʃʌɾ ɪɾ aʊt. hi fɔɹst ɪz hænz tə steɪ əɾ ɪz saɪdz. vɔɪɾ əɹ noʊ, ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ wən ðə læftɝ faɪnəli stɑpt.

Ba'alzamon laughed again, peal after mocking peal, until Rand wanted to cover his ears to shut it out. He forced his hands to stay at his sides. Void or no, they were trembling when the laughter finally stopped.

"ju wɝm, jə noʊ nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl. əz ɪɡnɝən əz ə biɾəl ʌndɝ ə ɹɑk, ən əz izəli kɹʌʃt. ðɪs stʃɹʌɡəl əz ɡɔn ɑn sɪns ðə moʊmən ə kɹieɪʃən. ɔlweɪz mɛn θɪŋk ɪɾ ə nu wɔɹ, bʌɾ ɪts dʒʌs ðə seɪm wɔɹ dɪskʌvɝɾ ənu. oʊnli naʊ tʃeɪnʒ bloʊz ɑn ðə wɪnz ə taɪm. tʃeɪnʒ. ðɪs taɪm ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ dʒɹɪftɪŋ bæk. ðoʊz pɹaʊɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ hu θɪŋk tə stæn jə ʌp əɡɛns mi. əl dʒɹɛs əm ɪn tʃeɪnz ən sɛn əm ɹʌnɪŋ neɪkəd tə də maɪ bɪɾɪŋ, əɹ stʌf ðɛɹ soʊlz ɪndə ðə pɪɾ ə dum tə skɹim fəɹ ɪtɝnəɾi. ɔl bʌt ðoʊz u ɔlɹɛɾi sɝv mi. ðəl stæn bʌɾ ə stɛp bɪniθ mi. jə kən tʃuz tə stænd wɪð ðɛm, wɪð ðə wɝld ɡɹɔvəlɪŋ ət jəɹ fit. aɪ ɔfɝ ɪt wʌn mɔɹ taɪm, wʌn læs taɪm. jə kən stæn əbʌv ðɛm, əbʌv ɛvɹi paʊɝ ən dəmɪnjən bʌt maɪn. ðəɹ əv bɪn taɪmz wən jə meɪd ðət tʃɔɪs, taɪmz wən jə lɪv lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə noʊ jəɹ paʊɝ."

"You worm, you know nothing at all. As ignorant as a beetle under a rock, and as easily crushed. This struggle has gone on since the moment of creation. Always men think it a new war, but it is just the same war discovered anew. Only now change blows on the winds of time. Change. This time there will be no drifting back. Those proud Aes Sedai who think to stand you up against me. I will dress them in chains and send them running naked to do my bidding, or stuff their souls into the Pit of Doom to scream for eternity. All but those who already serve me. They will stand but a step beneath me. You can choose to stand with them, with the world groveling at your feet. I offer it one more time, one last time. You can stand above them, above every power and dominion but mine. There have been times when you made that choice, times when you lived long enough to know your power."

dɪnaɪ hɪm! ɹænd ɡɹæb hoʊl tə wʌɾ i kəd dɪnaɪ. "noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝv ju. ənʌðɝ laɪ!"

Deny him! Rand grabbed hold to what he could deny. "No Aes Sedai serve you. Another lie!"

"ɪz ðət wʌt ðeɪ toʊl ju? tu θaʊzən jɪɹz əɡoʊ aɪ tʊk maɪ tʃɹɑləks əkɹɔs ðə wɝld, ən ivən əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ aɪ faʊn ðoʊz u nu dɪspɛɹ, hu nu ðə wɝl kəd nɑt stæn bɪfɔɹ ʃeɪtɑn. fəɹ tu θaʊzən jɪɹz ðə blæk ədʒɑ hæz dwɛlt əmʌŋ ði ʌðɝz, ənsin ɪn ðə ʃædoʊz. pɝhæps ivən ðoʊz u kleɪm tə hɛlp ju."

"Is that what they told you? Two thousand years ago I took my Trollocs across the world, and even among Aes Sedai I found those who knew despair, who knew the world could not stand before Shai'tan. For two thousand years the Black Ajah has dwelt among the others, unseen in the shadows. Perhaps even those who claim to help you."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ʃeɪk əweɪ ðə daʊts ðət keɪm wɛlɪŋ ʌp ɪn hɪm, ɔl ðə daʊts i hæd hæɾ əbaʊt mɔɪɹeɪn, əbaʊt wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑntəd wɪð hɪm, əbaʊt wʌt ʃi plæn fəɹ hɪm. "wʌt dʒju wɑn fɹəm mi?" hi kɹaɪd. dɪnaɪ hɪm! laɪt hɛlp mi dɪnaɪ hɪm!

Rand shook his head, trying to shake away the doubts that came welling up in him, all the doubts he had had about Moiraine, about what the Aes Sedai wanted with him, about what she planned for him. "What do you want from me?" he cried. Deny him! Light help me deny him!

"nil!" bælzəmən pɔɪntəd tə ðə flɔɹ əɾ ɪz fit. "nil, ən æknɑlɪdʒ mi jəɹ mæstɝ! ɪn ði ɛnd, jə wɪl. jəl bi maɪ kɹitʃɝ, əɹ jəl daɪ."

"Kneel!" Ba'alzamon pointed to the floor at his feet. "Kneel, and acknowledge me your master! In the end, you will. You will be my creature, or you will die."

ðə læst wɝɾ ɛkoʊd θɹu ðə ɹum, ɹɪvɝbɝeɪɾɪŋ bæk ɑn ɪtsɛlf, dʌbəlɪŋ ən ɹidʌbəlɪŋ, tɪl ɹænd θɹu ʌp ɪz ɑɹmz əz ɪf tə ʃild ɪz hɛd fɹəm ə bloʊ. stæɡɝɪŋ bæk əntɪl i θʌmpt ɪndə ðə teɪbəl, hi ʃaʊɾəd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒɹaʊn ðə saʊn ɪn ɪz ɪɹz. "nuuuuuuuuuuu!"

The last word echoed through the room, reverberating back on itself, doubling and redoubling, till Rand threw up his arms as if to shield his head from a blow. Staggering back until he thumped into the table, he shouted, trying to drown the sound in his ears. "Noooooooooooo!"

əz i kɹaɪɾ aʊt, hi spʌn, swipɪŋ ðə fɪɡjɝz tə ðə flɔɹ. sʌmθɪŋ stæbd ɪz hænd, bʌɾ i ɪɡnɔɹɾ ɪt, stɑmpɪŋ ðə kleɪ tə ʃeɪpləs smɪɹz ʌndɝfʊt. bʌt wən ɪz ʃaʊt feɪld, ði ɛkoʊ wɑz stɪl ðɛɹ, ən ɡɹoʊɪŋ stʃɹɔŋɝ:

As he cried out, he spun, sweeping the figures to the floor. Something stabbed his hand, but he ignored it, stomping the clay to shapeless smears underfoot. But when his shout failed, the echo was still there, and growing stronger:

daɪ-daɪ-daɪ-daɪ-daɪ-daɪ-daɪ-daɪ-daɪ-daɪ-daɪ-daɪ-daɪ-daɪ-daɪ-daɪ ðə saʊn pʊld ɑn ɪm laɪk ə wɝl pul, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪm ɪn, ɹɪpɪŋ ðə vɔɪɾ ɪn ɪz maɪn tə ʃɹɛdz. ðə laɪt dɪmd, ən ɪz vɪʒən nɛɹoʊd daʊn tə ə tʌnəl wɪð bælzəmən stændɪŋ tɔl ɪn ðə læst spɑɾ ə bɹaɪtnəs ət ði ɛnd, dwɪndəlɪŋ əntɪl ɪt wɑz ðə saɪz ə hɪz hænd, ə fɪŋɡɝneɪl, nʌθɪŋ. ɝaʊn ən ɝaʊn ði ɛkoʊ wɝl hɪm, daʊn ɪndə blæknəs ən dɛθ.

die-die-die-die-die-Die-Die-Die-Die-Die-DIE-DIE-DIE-DIE-DIE-DIE The sound pulled on him like a whirl pool, drawing him in, ripping the void in his mind to shreds. The light dimmed, and his vision narrowed down to a tunnel with Ba'alzamon standing tall in the last spot of brightness at the end, dwindling until it was the size of his hand, a fingernail, nothing. Around and around the echo whirled him, down into blackness and death.

ðə θʌmp əz i hɪt ðə flɔɹ woʊk hɪm, stɪl stʃɹʌɡəlɪŋ tə swɪm ʌp aʊɾ ə ðət dɑɹknəs. ðə ɹum wɑz dɑɹk, bʌt nɑt soʊ dɑɹk əz ðæt. fɹæntəkəli hi tʃɹaɪd tə sɛntɝ ɑn ðə fleɪm, tə ʃʌvəl fɪɹ ɪndə ɪt, bʌt ðə kɑm ə ðə vɔɪɾ ɪluɾɪd hɪm. tʃɹɛmɝz ɹæn daʊn ɪz ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz, bʌɾ i hɛl ði ɪmədʒ ə ðə sɪŋɡəl fleɪm əntɪl ðə blʌd stɑpt paʊndɪŋ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz.

The thump as he hit the floor woke him, still struggling to swim up out of that darkness. The room was dark, but not so dark as that. Frantically he tried to center on the flame, to shovel fear into it, but the calm of the void eluded him. Tremors ran down his arms and legs, but he held the image of the single flame until the blood stopped pounding in his ears.

mæt wɑz tɔsɪŋ ən twɪstɪŋ ɑn ɪz bɛd, ɡɹoʊnɪŋ ɪn ɪz slip. ". . . dɪnaɪ ju, dɪnaɪ ju, dɪnaɪ ju. . . ." ɪt feɪɾəd ɔf ɪndə ʌnɪntɛlədʒəbəl moʊnz.

Mat was tossing and twisting on his bed, groaning in his sleep. ". . . deny you, deny you, deny you. . . ." It faded off into unintelligible moans.

ɹænd ɹitʃt aʊt tə ʃeɪk ɪm əweɪk, ən ət ðə fɝs tʌtʃ mæt sæɾ ʌp wɪð ə stʃɹæŋɡəld ɡɹʌnt. fəɹ ə mɪnət mæt stɛɹɾ ɝaʊnd waɪldli, ðən dʒɹu ə lɔŋ, ʃʌɾɝɪŋ bɹɛθ ən dʒɹɑpt ɪz hɛɾ ɪndə hɪz hænz. əbɹʌpli hi twɪstəɾ ɝaʊnd, dɪɡɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪz pɪloʊ, ðən sæŋk bæk klʌtʃɪŋ ðə ɹubi-hɪltɪd dæɡɝ ɪn boʊθ hænz ɑn ɪz tʃɛst. hi tɝn ɪz hɛd tə lʊk ət ɹænd, hɪz feɪs hɪɾən ɪn ʃædoʊ. "hiz bæk, ɹænd."

Rand reached out to shake him awake, and at the first touch Mat sat up with a strangled grunt. For a minute Mat stared around wildly, then drew a long, shuddering breath and dropped his head into his hands. Abruptly he twisted around, digging under his pillow, then sank back clutching the ruby-hilted dagger in both hands on his chest. He turned his head to look at Rand, his face hidden in shadow. "He's back, Rand."

"aɪ noʊ."

"I know."

mæt nɑɾəd. "ðɛɹ wɝ ðiz θɹi fɪɡjɝz. . . ."

Mat nodded. "There were these three figures. . . ."

"aɪ sɔ ðɛm, tu."

"I saw them, too."

"hi noʊz u aɪ æm, ɹænd. aɪ pɪkt ʌp ðə wʌn wɪð ðə dæɡɝ, ən i sɛd, 'soʊ ðæts u jə ɑɹ.' ən wən aɪ lʊkt əɡɛn, ðə fɪɡjɝ hæd maɪ feɪs. maɪ feɪs, ɹænd! ɪt lʊk laɪk flɛʃ. ɪt fɛlt laɪk flɛʃ. laɪt hɛlp mi, aɪ kəd fil maɪ oʊn hænd ɡɹɪpɪŋ mi, laɪk aɪ wɑz ðə fɪɡjɝ."

"He knows who I am, Rand. I picked up the one with the dagger, and he said, 'So that's who you are.' And when I looked again, the figure had my face. My face, Rand! It looked like flesh. It felt like flesh. Light help me, I could feel my own hand gripping me, like I was the figure."

ɹænd wɑz saɪlən fəɹ ə moʊmənt. "ju hæv tə kip dɪnaɪɪŋ hɪm, mæt."

Rand was silent for a moment. "You have to keep denying him, Mat."

"aɪ dɪd, ən i læft. hi kɛp tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt səm ɪtɝnəl wɔɹ, ən seɪɪŋ wid mɛt laɪk ðəɾ ə θaʊzən taɪmz bɪfɔɹ, ænd. . . . laɪt, ɹænd, ðə dɑɹk wʌn noʊz mi."

"I did, and he laughed. He kept talking about some eternal war, and saying we'd met like that a thousand times before, and. . . . Light, Rand, the Dark One knows me."

"hi sɛd ðə seɪm θɪŋ tə mi. aɪ doʊn θɪŋk i dʌz," hi æɾəd sloʊli. "aɪ doʊn θɪŋk i noʊz wɪtʃ ʌv ʌs. . . ." wɪtʃ ʌv əs wʌt?

"He said the same thing to me. I don't think he does," he added slowly. "I don't think he knows which of us. . . ." Which of us what?

əz i lɛvɝd hɪmsɛlf ʌp, peɪn stæbd ɪz hænd. meɪkɪŋ ɪz weɪ tə ðə teɪbəl, hi mænədʒ tə ɡɛt ðə kændəl lɪɾ æftɝ θɹi tʃɹaɪz, ðən spɹɛɾ ɪz hæn oʊpən ɪn ðə laɪt. dʒɹɪvən ɪndə hɪz pɑm wɑz ə θɪk splɪntɝ ə dɑɹk wʊd, smuð ən pɑlɪʃt ɑn wʌn saɪd. hi stɛɹɾ əɾ ɪt, nɑt bɹiðɪŋ. əbɹʌpli hi wɑz pæntɪŋ, plʌkɪŋ ət ðə splɪntɝ, fʌmbəlɪŋ wɪð heɪst.

As he levered himself up, pain stabbed his hand. Making his way to the table, he managed to get the candle lit after three tries, then spread his hand open in the light. Driven into his palm was a thick splinter of dark wood, smooth and polished on one side. He stared at it, not breathing. Abruptly he was panting, plucking at the splinter, fumbling with haste.

"wʌts ðə mæɾɝ?" mæt æskt.

"What's the matter?" Mat asked.

"nʌθɪŋ."

"Nothing."

faɪnəli hi hæɾ ɪt, ən ə ʃɑɹp jæŋk pʊld ɪt fɹi. wɪð ə ɡɹʌn ə dɪsɡʌst i dʒɹɑpt ɪt, bʌt ðə ɡɹʌn fɹoʊz ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt. əz sun əz ðə splɪntɝ lɛft ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, ɪt vænɪʃt.

Finally he had it, and a sharp yank pulled it free. With a grunt of disgust he dropped it, but the grunt froze in his throat. As soon as the splinter left his fingers, it vanished.

ðə waʊnd wɑz stɪl ðəɹ ɪn ɪz hænd, ðoʊ, bliɾɪŋ. ðəɹ wɑz wɔɾɝ ɪn ðə stoʊnwɛɹ pɪtʃɝ. hi fɪl ðə beɪsən, hɪz hænz ʃeɪkɪŋ soʊ ðəɾ i splæʃt wɔɾɝ ɑntu ðə teɪbəl. hɝidli hi wɑʃt ɪz hænz, niɾɪŋ ɪz pɑm tɪl ɪz θʌm bɹɔt mɔɹ blʌd, ðən wɑʃt əm əɡɛn. ðə θɔɾ ə ðə smɔləst slɪvɝ ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ ɪn ɪz flɛʃ tɛɹəfaɪd hɪm.

The wound was still there in his hand, though, bleeding. There was water in the stoneware pitcher. He filled the basin, his hands shaking so that he splashed water onto the table. Hurriedly he washed his hands, kneading his palm till his thumb brought more blood, then washed them again. The thought of the smallest sliver remaining in his flesh terrified him.

"laɪt," mæt sɛd, "hi meɪd mi fil dɝɾi, tu." bʌɾ i stɪl leɪ wɛɹ i wɑz, hoʊldɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ ɪn boʊθ hænz.

"Light," Mat said, "he made me feel dirty, too." But he still lay where he was, holding the dagger in both hands.

"jɛs," ɹænd sɛd. "dɝɾi." hi fʌmbəld ə taʊəl fɹəm ðə stæk bɪsaɪd ðə beɪsən. ðəɹ wɑz ə nɑk ət ðə dɔɹ, ən i dʒʌmpt. ɪt keɪm əɡɛn. "jɛs?" hi sɛd.

"Yes," Rand said. "Dirty." He fumbled a towel from the stack beside the basin. There was a knock at the door, and he jumped. It came again. "Yes?" he said.

mɔɪɹeɪn pʊɾ əɹ hɛɾ ɪndə ðə ɹum. "ju ɑɹ əweɪk ɔlɹɛɾi. ɡʊd. dʒɹɛs kwɪkli ən kʌm daʊn. wi mʌs bi əweɪ bɪfɔɹ fɝs laɪt."

Moiraine put her head into the room. "You are awake already. Good. Dress quickly and come down. We must be away before first light."

"naʊ?" mæt ɡɹoʊnd. "wi hævən hæɾ ən aʊɝz slip jɛt."

"Now?" Mat groaned. "We haven't had an hour's sleep yet."

"æn aʊɝ?" ʃi sɛd. "ju hæv hæd fɔɹ. naʊ hɝi, wi də nɑɾ əv mʌtʃ taɪm."

"An hour?" she said. "You have had four. Now hurry, we do not have much time."

ɹænd ʃɛɹɾ ə kənfjuz lʊk wɪð mæt. hi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɛvɹi sɛkən ə ðə dʒɹim klɪɹli. ɪt hæd bɪɡʌn əz sun əz i kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, ən læstəɾ oʊnli mɪnəts.

Rand shared a confused look with Mat. He could remember every second of the dream clearly. It had begun as soon as he closed his eyes, and lasted only minutes.

sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðəɾ ɪkstʃeɪnʒ mʌst əv kəmjunəkeɪɾɪd ɪtsɛlf tə mɔɪɹeɪn. ʃi ɡeɪv əm ə pɛnətʃɹeɪɾɪŋ lʊk ən keɪm ɔl ðə weɪ ɪn. "wʌɾ əz hæpənd? ðə dʒɹimz?"

Something in that exchange must have communicated itself to Moiraine. She gave them a penetrating look and came all the way in. "What has happened? The dreams?"

"hi noʊz u aɪ æm," mæt sɛd. "ðə dɑɹk wʌn noʊz maɪ feɪs." ɹænd hɛld ʌp ɪz hænd wɝdləsli, pɑm təwɔɹd hɝ. ivən ɪn ðə ʃæɾoʊd laɪt fɹəm ðə wʌn kændəl ðə blʌd wɑz pleɪn.

"He knows who I am," Mat said. "The Dark One knows my face." Rand held up his hand wordlessly, palm toward her. Even in the shadowed light from the one candle the blood was plain.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ən ɡɹæspt ɪz əphɛl hænd, hɝ θʌm əkɹɔs ɪz pɑm kʌvɝɪŋ ðə waʊnd. koʊl pɪɹst ɪm tə ðə boʊn, soʊ tʃɪl ðəɾ ɪz fɪŋɡɝz kɹæmpt ən i hæd tə faɪt tə kip əm oʊpən. wən ʃi tʊk əɹ fɪŋɡɝz əweɪ, ðə tʃɪl wɛnt, tu.

The Aes Sedai stepped forward and grasped his upheld hand, her thumb across his palm covering the wound. Cold pierced him to the bone, so chill that his fingers cramped and he had to fight to keep them open. When she took her fingers away, the chill went, too.

hi tɝn ɪz hænd, ðɛn, stʌnd, skɹʌb ðə θɪn smɪɹ ə blʌɾ əweɪ. ðə waʊnd wɑz ɡɔn. sloʊli hi ɹeɪzd ɪz aɪz tə mit ðoʊz ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

He turned his hand, then, stunned, scrubbed the thin smear of blood away. The wound was gone. Slowly he raised his eyes to meet those of the Aes Sedai.

"hɝi," ʃi sɛd sɔfli. "taɪm ɡɹoʊz vɛɹi ʃɔɹt."

"Hurry," she said softly. "Time grows very short."

hi nu ʃi wɑz nɑt spikɪŋ ə ðə taɪm fəɹ ðɛɹ livɪŋ ɛnimɔɹ.

He knew she was not speaking of the time for their leaving anymore.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾifɔɹ


CHAPTER 44

ðə dɑɹk əlɔŋ ðə weɪz


The Dark Along the Ways

ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ dɔn ɹænd fɑloʊd mɔɪɹeɪn daʊn tə ðə bæk hɔl, wɛɹ mæstɝ ɡɪl ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ weɪɾɪŋ, nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin əz æŋkʃəsli əz lɔɪəl, pɛɹɪn ɔlmoʊst əz kɑm əz ðə wɔɹɾɝ. mæt steɪɾ ɑn ɹændz hilz əz ɪf i wɝ əfɹeɪd tə bi ivən ə lɪɾəl əloʊn naʊ, ivən əz mʌtʃ əz ə fju fiɾ əweɪ. ðə kʊk ən əɹ hɛlpɝz stʃɹeɪɾənd, stɛɹɪŋ əz ðə pɑɹɾi pæst saɪlənli ɪndə ðə kɪtʃən, ɔlɹɛɾi bɹaɪtli lɪɾ ən hɑt wɪð pɹɛpɝeɪʃənz fəɹ bɹɛkfəst. ɪt wɑz nɑt juʒəwəl fəɹ peɪtʃɹənz ə ði ɪn tə bi ʌp ən aʊɾ ət ðəɾ aʊɝ. ət mæstɝ ɡɪlz suðɪŋ wɝdz, ðə kʊk ɡeɪv ə laʊd snɪf ən slæpt əɹ doʊ daʊn hɑɹd. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl bæk tə tɛndɪŋ ɡɹɪɾəlz ən niɾɪŋ doʊ bɪfɔɹ ɹænd ɹitʃt ðə steɪbliɑɹd dɔɹ.

In the darkness just before dawn Rand followed Moiraine down to the back hall, where Master Gill and the others were waiting, Nynaeve and Egwene as anxiously as Loial, Perrin almost as calm as the Warder. Mat stayed on Rand's heels as if he were afraid to be even a little alone now, even as much as a few feet away. The cook and her helpers straightened, staring as the party passed silently into the kitchen, already brightly lit and hot with preparations for breakfast. It was not usual for patrons of the inn to be up and out at that hour. At Master Gill's soothing words, the cook gave a loud sniff and slapped her dough down hard. They were all back to tending griddles and kneading dough before Rand reached the stableyard door.

aʊtsaɪd, ðə naɪt wɑz stɪl pɪtʃ-blæk. tə ɹænd, ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls wɑz oʊnli ə dɑɹkɝ ʃædoʊ ət bɛst. hi fɑloʊd ði ɪnkipɝ ən læn blaɪnli, blaɪn ɪn tʃɹuθ, hoʊpɪŋ mæstɝ ɡɪlz nɑlədʒ ə hɪz oʊn steɪbliɑɹɾ ən ðə wɔɹɾɝz ɪnstɪŋks wəd ɡɛɾ əm əkɹɔs ɪt wɪθaʊt sʌmwʌn bɹeɪkɪŋ ə lɛɡ. lɔɪəl stʌmbəl mɔɹ ðən wʌns.

Outside, the night was still pitch-black. To Rand, everyone else was only a darker shadow at best. He followed the innkeeper and Lan blindly, blind in truth, hoping Master Gill's knowledge of his own stableyard and the Warder's instincts would get them across it without someone breaking a leg. Loial stumbled more than once.

"aɪ doʊn si waɪ wi kæn əv dʒʌst wʌn laɪt," ði oʊɡiɝ ɡɹʌmbəld. "wi doʊnt ɡoʊ ɹʌnɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk ɪn ðə stɛɾɪŋ. ɪm ən oʊɡiɝ, nɑɾ ə kæt." ɹænd hæɾ ə sʌɾən ɪmədʒ ə lɔɪəlz tʌftəɾ ɪɹz twɪtʃɪŋ ɪɹɪɾəbli.

"I don't see why we can't have just one light," the Ogier grumbled. "We don't go running about in the dark in the stedding. I'm an Ogier, not a cat." Rand had a sudden image of Loial's tufted ears twitching irritably.

ðə steɪbəl lumd ʌp sʌɾənli aʊɾ ə ðə naɪt, ə θɹɛɾənɪŋ mæs əntɪl ðə steɪbəl dɔɹ kɹikt oʊpən, spɪlɪŋ ə nɛɹoʊ stʃɹim ə laɪɾ ɪndə ðə jɑɹd. ði ɪnkipɝ oʊnli oʊpən ɪt waɪɾ ɪnʌf fəɹ əm tə ɡoʊ ɪn wʌn əɾ ə taɪm, ən heɪstəli pʊld ɪt tə bɪhaɪn pɛɹɪn, ɔlmoʊs klɪpɪŋ ɪz hilz. ɹænd blɪŋkt ɪn ðə sʌɾən laɪɾ ɪnsaɪd.

The stable loomed up suddenly out of the night, a threatening mass until the stable door creaked open, spilling a narrow stream of light into the yard. The innkeeper only opened it wide enough for them to go in one at a time, and hastily pulled it to behind Perrin, almost clipping his heels. Rand blinked in the sudden light inside.

ðə steɪbəlmən wɝ nɑt sɝpɹaɪz baɪ ðɛɹ əpɪɹəns, əz ðə kʊk hæd bɪn. ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz wɝ sæɾəld ən weɪɾɪŋ. mændɑɹb stʊɾ ɛɹəɡənli, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ɛvɹiwʌn bʌt læn, bʌɾ ɑldib stʃɹɛtʃt əɹ noʊz aʊt tə nʌzəl mɔɪɹeɪnz hænd. ðəɹ wɑz ə pæk hɔɹs, bʌlki wɪð wɪkɝ pænɪɝz, ən ə hjudʒ ænəməl wɪð hɛɹi fɛtlɑks, tɔlɝ ivən ðən ðə wɔɹɾɝz stæljən, fəɹ lɔɪəl. ɪt lʊk bɪɡ ɪnʌf tə pʊl ə loʊɾəd heɪweɪn baɪ ɪtsɛlf, bʌt kəmpɛɹd wɪð ði oʊɡiɝ ɪt simd ə poʊni.

The stablemen were not surprised by their appearance, as the cook had been. Their horses were saddled and waiting. Mandarb stood arrogantly, ignoring everyone but Lan, but Aldieb stretched her nose out to nuzzle Moiraine's hand. There was a pack horse, bulky with wicker panniers, and a huge animal with hairy fetlocks, taller even than the Warder's stallion, for Loial. It looked big enough to pull a loaded haywain by itself, but compared with the Ogier it seemed a pony.

lɔɪəl aɪd ðə bɪɡ hɔɹs ən mʌɾɝd daʊtfəli, "maɪ oʊn fiɾ əv ɔlweɪz bɪn ɡʊɾ ɪnʌf."

Loial eyed the big horse and muttered doubtfully, "My own feet have always been good enough."

mæstɝ ɡɪl moʊʃən tə ɹænd. ði ɪnkipɝ wɑz lɛndɪŋ ɪm ə beɪ ɔlmoʊs ðə kʌlɝ ə hɪz oʊn hɛɹ, tɔl ən dip ə tʃɛst, bʌt wɪð nʌn ə ðə faɪɝ ɪn ɪz stɛp ðət klaʊd hæd hæd, ɹænd wɑz ɡlæd tə si. mæstɝ ɡɪl sɛɾ ɪz neɪm wɑz ɹɛd.

Master Gill motioned to Rand. The innkeeper was lending him a bay almost the color of his own hair, tall and deep of chest, but with none of the fire in his step that Cloud had had, Rand was glad to see. Master Gill said his name was Red.

ɛɡwin wɛn stʃɹeɪt tə bɛlə, ən nɪneɪiv tə hɝ lɔŋ-lɛɡəd mɛɹ.

Egwene went straight to Bela, and Nynaeve to her long-legged mare.

mæt bɹɔɾ ɪz dʌn-kʌlɝd hɔɹs oʊvɝ baɪ ɹænd. "pɛɹɪnz meɪkɪŋ mi nɝvəs," hi mʌɾɝd. ɹænd lʊkt əɾ ɪm ʃɑɹpli. "wɛl, hiz æktɪŋ stʃɹeɪnʒ. doʊn jə si ɪt, tu? aɪ swɛɹ ɪts nɑt maɪ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən, əɹ . . . ɔɹ. . . ."

Mat brought his dun-colored horse over by Rand. "Perrin's making me nervous," he muttered. Rand looked at him sharply. "Well, he's acting strange. Don't you see it, too? I swear it's not my imagination, or . . . or. . . ."

ɹænd nɑɾəd. nɑt ðə dæɡɝ teɪkɪŋ hoʊld ə hɪm əɡɛn, θæŋk ðə laɪt. "hi ɪz, mæt, bʌt dʒʌs bi izi. mɔɪɹeɪn noʊz əbaʊt . . . wʌtɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz. pɛɹɪnz faɪn." hi wɪʃt i kəd bɪliv ɪt, bʌɾ ɪt sim tə sæɾəsfaɪ mæt, ə lɪɾəl ət list.

Rand nodded. Not the dagger taking hold of him again, thank the Light. "He is, Mat, but just be easy. Moiraine knows about . . . Whatever it is. Perrin's fine." He wished he could believe it, but it seemed to satisfy Mat, a little at least.

"ʌv kɔɹs," mæt sɛd heɪstəli, stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ pɛɹɪn aʊɾ ə ðə kɔɹnɝ ə hɪz aɪ. "aɪ nɛvɝ sɛɾ i wɑznt."

"Of course," Mat said hastily, still watching Perrin out of the corner of his eye. "I never said he wasn't."

mæstɝ ɡɪl kənfɝd wɪð ðə hɛd ɡɹum. ðət lɛðɝi-skɪn mæn, wɪð ə feɪs laɪk wʌn ə ðə hɔɹsəz, nʌkəld ɪz fɔɹhɛɾ ən hɝid tə ðə bæk ə ðə steɪbəl. ði ɪnkipɝ tɝn tə mɔɪɹeɪn wɪð ə sæɾəsfaɪd smaɪl ɑn ɪz ɹaʊn feɪs. "ɹæmi sɛz ðə weɪ ɪz klɪɹ, ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Master Gill conferred with the head groom. That leathery-skinned man, with a face like one of the horses, knuckled his forehead and hurried to the back of the stable. The innkeeper turned to Moiraine with a satisfied smile on his round face. "Ramey says the way is clear, Aes Sedai."

ðə ɹɪɹ wɔl ə ðə steɪbəl əpɪɹd sɑləɾ ən staʊt, laɪnd wɪð hɛvi ɹæks ə tulz. ɹæmi ən ənʌðɝ steɪbəlmən klɪɹɾ əweɪ ðə heɪfɔɹks, ɹeɪks, ən ʃʌvəlz, ðən ɹitʃt bɪhaɪn ðə ɹæks tə mənɪpjəleɪt hɪɾən lætʃəz. əbɹʌpli ə sɛkʃən ə ðə wɔl swʌŋ ɪnwɝɾ ɑn hɪnʒɪz soʊ wɛl kənsil ðət ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ i kəd faɪn əm ivən wɪð ðə dɪsɡaɪz dɔɹ stændɪŋ oʊpən. laɪt fɹəm ðə steɪbəl ɪluməneɪɾəd ə bɹɪk wɔl oʊnli ə fju fiɾ əweɪ.

The rear wall of the stable appeared solid and stout, lined with heavy racks of tools. Ramey and another stableman cleared away the hayforks, rakes, and shovels, then reached behind the racks to manipulate hidden latches. Abruptly a section of the wall swung inward on hinges so well concealed that Rand was not sure he could find them even with the disguised door standing open. Light from the stable illuminated a brick wall only a few feet away.

"ɪts oʊnli ə nɛɹoʊ ɹʌn bɪtwin bɪldɪŋz," ði ɪnkipɝ sɛd, "bʌt noʊbɑdi aʊtsaɪd ðɪs steɪbəl noʊz ðɛɹz ə weɪ ɪndə ɪt fɹəm hɪɹ. waɪtkloʊks əɹ waɪt kɑkeɪdz, ðɛɹəl nɑt bi ɛni wɑtʃɝz tə si wɛɹ jə kʌm aʊt."

"It's only a narrow run between buildings," the innkeeper said, "but nobody outside this stable knows there's a way into it from here. Whitecloaks or white cockades, there'll not be any watchers to see where you come out."

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ nɑɾəd. "ɹɪmɛmbɝ, ɡʊɾ ɪnkipɝ, ɪf jə fɪɹ ɛni tʃɹʌbəl fɹəm ðɪs, ɹaɪt tə ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪ, ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ, ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən ʃɪl hɛlp. aɪ fɪɹ maɪ sɪstɝz ən aɪ hæv ə ɡʊd dil tə pʊt ɹaɪɾ ɔlɹɛɾi fəɹ ðoʊz u hæv hɛlp mi."

The Aes Sedai nodded. "Remember, good innkeeper, if you fear any trouble from this, write to Sheriam Sedai, of the Blue Ajah, in Tar Valon, and she will help. I fear my sisters and I have a good deal to put right already for those who have helped me."

mæstɝ ɡɪl læft; nɑt ðə læf ʌv ə wɝid mæn. "waɪ, ɛɛs sədaɪ, juv ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɪvən mi ði oʊnli ɪn ɪn ɔl ə keɪɛmlɪn wɪθaʊɾ ɛni ɹæts. wʌt mɔɹ kəɾ aɪ æsk fɔɹ? aɪ kən dʌbəl maɪ kʌstəm ɑn ðəɾ əloʊn." hɪz ɡɹɪn feɪɾəd ɪndə sɪɹiəsnəs. "wʌtɛvɝ jəɹ ʌp tə, ðə kwin hoʊlz wɪð tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən aɪ hoʊld wɪð ðə kwin, soʊ ðəfɝst wɪʃ jə wɛl. ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ju, ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin jə ɔl."

Master Gill laughed; not the laugh of a worried man. "Why, Aes Sedai, you've already given me the only inn in all of Caemlyn without any rats. What more could I ask for? I can double my custom on that alone." His grin faded into seriousness. "Whatever you're up to, the Queen holds with Tar Valon, and I hold with the Queen, so I wish you well. The Light illumine you, Aes Sedai. The Light illumine you all."

"ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ju, ɔlsoʊ, mæstɝ ɡɪl," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd wɪð ə baʊ ʌv əɹ hɛd. "bʌɾ ɪf ðə laɪɾ ɪz tə ʃaɪn ɑn ɛni ʌv ʌs, wi mʌs bi kwɪk." bɹɪskli ʃi tɝn tə lɔɪəl. "ɑɹ jə ɹɛɾi?"

"The Light illumine you, also, Master Gill," Moiraine replied with a bow of her head. "But if the Light is to shine on any of us, we must be quick." Briskly she turned to Loial. "Are you ready?"

wɪð ə wɛɹi lʊk əɾ ɪts tiθ, ði oʊɡiɝ tʊk ðə ɹeɪnz ə ðə bɪɡ hɔɹs. tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip ðət maʊð ðə lɛŋθ ə ðə ɹeɪnz fɹəm ɪz hænd, hi lɛd ði ænəməl tə ði oʊpənɪŋ ət ðə bæk ə ðə steɪbəl. ɹæmi hɑp fɹəm wʌn fʊt tə ði ʌðɝ, ɪmpeɪʃən tə kloʊz ɪɾ əɡɛn. fəɹ ə moʊmən lɔɪəl pɔzd wɪð ɪz hɛd kɑkt əz ɪf filɪŋ ə bɹiz ɑn ɪz tʃik. "ðɪs weɪ," hi sɛd, ən tɝn daʊn ðə nɛɹoʊ æli.

With a wary look at its teeth, the Ogier took the reins of the big horse. Trying to keep that mouth the length of the reins from his hand, he led the animal to the opening at the back of the stable. Ramey hopped from one foot to the other, impatient to close it again. For a moment Loial paused with his head cocked as if feeling a breeze on his cheek. "This way," he said, and turned down the narrow alley.

mɔɪɹeɪn fɑloʊd ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn lɔɪəlz hɔɹs, ðən ɹænd, ən mæt. ɹænd hæd ðə fɝs tɝn liɾɪŋ ðə pæk hɔɹs. nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin meɪd ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə kɑləm, wɪð pɛɹɪn bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ən læn bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹɪɹ. ðə hɪɾən dɔɹ swʌŋ heɪstəli ʃʌɾ əz sun əz mændɑɹb stɛpt ɪndə ðə dɝɾ æliweɪ. ðə snɪk-snɪk ə lætʃəz lɑkɪŋ, ʃʌɾɪŋ əm ɔf, saʊndəɾ ənnətʃɝəli laʊd tə ɹænd.

Moiraine followed right behind Loial's horse, then Rand, and Mat. Rand had the first turn leading the pack horse. Nynaeve and Egwene made the middle of the column, with Perrin behind them, and Lan bringing up the rear. The hidden door swung hastily shut as soon as Mandarb stepped into the dirt alleyway. The snick-snick of latches locking, shutting them off, sounded unnaturally loud to Rand.

ðə ɹʌn, əz mæstɝ ɡɪl hæd kɔld ɪt, wɑz vɛɹi nɛɹoʊ ɪndid, ən ivən dɑɹkɝ ðən ðə steɪbliɑɹd, ɪf ðət wɑz pɑsəbəl. tɔl, blæŋk wɔlz ə bɹɪk əɹ wʊd laɪn boʊθ saɪdz, wɪð oʊnli ə nɛɹoʊ stʃɹɪp ə blæk skaɪ oʊvɝhɛd. ðə bɪɡ, woʊvən bæskəts slʌŋ ɑn ðə pæk hɔɹs skɹeɪp ðə bɪldɪŋz ɑn boʊθ saɪdz. ðə pænɪɝz bʌlʒd wɪð səplaɪz fəɹ ðə dʒɝni, moʊst ʌv ɪt kleɪ dʒɑɹz fɪld wɪð ɔɪl. ə bʌndəl ə poʊlz wɑz læʃt lɛŋθwaɪz daʊn ðə hɔɹsəz bæk, ən itʃ hæɾ ə læntɝn swɪŋɪŋ ət ði ɛn ʌv ɪt. ɪn ðə weɪz, lɔɪəl sɛd, ɪt wɑz dɑɹkɝ ðən ðə dɑɹkəs naɪt.

The run, as Master Gill had called it, was very narrow indeed, and even darker than the stableyard, if that was possible. Tall, blank walls of brick or wood lined both sides, with only a narrow strip of black sky overhead. The big, woven baskets slung on the pack horse scraped the buildings on both sides. The panniers bulged with supplies for the journey, most of it clay jars filled with oil. A bundle of poles was lashed lengthwise down the horse's back, and each had a lantern swinging at the end of it. In the Ways, Loial said, it was darker than the darkest night.

ðə pɑɹʃəli-fɪld læntɝnz slɑʃt wɪð ðə moʊʃən ə ðə hɔɹs, ən klɪŋkt əɡɛnst itʃ ʌðɝ wɪð ə tɪni saʊnd. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə vɛɹi laʊd nɔɪz, bʌɾ ɪn ði aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ dɔn keɪɛmlɪn wɑz kwaɪət. saɪlənt. ðə dʌl mətælɪk klɪŋks saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ kəd bi hɝɾ ə maɪl əweɪ.

The partially-filled lanterns sloshed with the motion of the horse, and clinked against each other with a tinny sound. It was not a very loud noise, but in the hour before dawn Caemlyn was quiet. Silent. The dull metallic clinks sounded as if they could be heard a mile away.

wən ðə ɹʌn lɛɾ aʊɾ ɪndə ə stʃɹit, lɔɪəl tʃoʊz ɪz dɝɛkʃən wɪθaʊɾ ə pɔz. hi sim tə noʊ ɪɡzækli wɛɹ i wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ, naʊ, əz ɪf ðə ɹuɾ i niɾəd tə fɑloʊ wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ klɪɹɝ. ɹænd dɪd nɑɾ ʌndɝstæn haʊ ði oʊɡiɝ kəd faɪn ðə weɪɡeɪt, ən lɔɪəl hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə ɪkspleɪn vɛɹi wɛl. hi dʒʌs nu, hi sɛd; hi kəd fil ɪt. lɔɪəl kleɪmd ɪt wɑz laɪk tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɪkspleɪn haʊ tə bɹið.

When the run let out into a street, Loial chose his direction without a pause. He seemed to know exactly where he was going, now, as if the route he needed to follow was becoming clearer. Rand did not understand how the Ogier could find the Waygate, and Loial had not been able to explain very well. He just knew, he said; he could feel it. Loial claimed it was like trying to explain how to breathe.

əz ðeɪ hɝiɾ ʌp ðə stʃɹit ɹænd lʊk bæk təwɔɹd ðə kɔɹnɝ wɛɹ ðə kwinz blɛsɪŋ leɪ. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə læmɡwɪn, ðəɹ wɝ stɪl hæf ə dʌzən waɪtkloʊks nɑt fɑɹ daʊn fɹəm ðət kɔɹnɝ. ðɛɹ ɪntʃɹəst wɑz ɔl ɑn ði ɪn, bʌɾ ə nɔɪz wəd ʃʊɹli bɹɪŋ ðɛm. noʊ wʌn wɑz aʊɾ ət ðɪs aʊɝ fəɹ ə ɹɛpjəɾəbəl ɹizən. ðə hɔɹs ʃuz sim tə ɹɪŋ ɑn ðə peɪvɪŋ stoʊnz laɪk bɛlz; ðə læntɝnz klæɾɝd əz ɪf ðə pæk hɔɹs wɝ ʃeɪkɪŋ əm dɪlɪbɝətli. nɑɾ əntɪl ðeɪ hæd ɹaʊndəɾ ənʌðɝ kɔɹnɝ dɪɾ i stɑp lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. hi hɝd ɹɪliv saɪz fɹəm ði ʌðɝ ɛmənz fildɝz əz ðeɪ keɪm ɹaʊn ɪt, tu.

As they hurried up the street Rand looked back toward the corner where The Queen's Blessing lay. According to Lamgwin, there were still half a dozen Whitecloaks not far down from that corner. Their interest was all on the inn, but a noise would surely bring them. No one was out at this hour for a reputable reason. The horse shoes seemed to ring on the paving stones like bells; the lanterns clattered as if the pack horse were shaking them deliberately. Not until they had rounded another corner did he stop looking over his shoulder. He heard relieved sighs from the other Emond's Fielders as they came round it, too.

lɔɪəl əpɪɹd tə bi fɑloʊɪŋ ðə moʊs dɝɛk pæθ tə ðə weɪɡeɪt, wɛɹɛvɝ ɪt tʊk ðɛm. səmtaɪmz ðeɪ tʃɹɑɾəd daʊn bɹɔɾ ævənuz, ɛmpti seɪv fəɹ ən əkeɪʒənəl dɔɡ skʌlkɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹk. səmtaɪmz ðeɪ hɝiɾ əlɔŋ æliz əz nɛɹoʊ əz ðə steɪbəl ɹʌn, wɛɹ θɪŋz skwɪʃt ʌndɝ ən ənwɛɹi stɛp. nɪneɪiv kəmpleɪn sɔfli əbaʊt ðə ɹɪzʌltɪŋ smɛlz, bʌt noʊ wʌn sloʊd daʊn.

Loial appeared to be following the most direct path to the Waygate, wherever it took them. Sometimes they trotted down broad avenues, empty save for an occasional dog skulking in the dark. Sometimes they hurried along alleys as narrow as the stable run, where things squished under an unwary step. Nynaeve complained softly about the resulting smells, but no one slowed down.

ðə dɑɹknəs bɪɡæn tə lɛsən, feɪɾɪŋ təwɔɹɾ ə dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ. feɪnt ɡlɪmɝz ə dɔn pɝl ðə skaɪ əbʌv ði istɝn ɹuftɑps. ə fju pipəl əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðə stʃɹits, bʌndəld ʌp əɡɛns ði ɝli koʊld, hɛdz daʊn waɪl ðeɪ jɛt dʒɹimd ə ðɛɹ bɛdz. moʊs peɪd noʊ maɪn tə ɛniwʌn ɛls. oʊnli ə hændfʊl ivən ɡlænst ət ðə laɪn ə pipəl ən hɔɹsəz wɪð lɔɪəl əɾ ɪts hɛd, ən oʊnli wʌn ə ðoʊz tʃɹuli sɔ ðɛm.

The darkness began to lessen, fading toward a dark gray. Faint glimmers of dawn pearled the sky above the eastern rooftops. A few people appeared on the streets, bundled up against the early cold, heads down while they yet dreamed of their beds. Most paid no mind to anyone else. Only a handful even glanced at the line of people and horses with Loial at its head, and only one of those truly saw them.

ðət wʌn mæn flɪkt ɪz aɪz ət ðɛm, dʒʌs laɪk ði ʌðɝz, ɔlɹɛɾi sɪŋkɪŋ bæk ɪndə hɪz oʊn θɔts wən sʌɾənli hi stʌmbəld ən ɔlmoʊs fɛl, tɝnɪŋ hɪmsɛlf bæk ɝaʊn tə stɛɹ. ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli laɪɾ ɪnʌf tə si ʃeɪps, bʌt ðət wɑz tu mʌtʃ. sin əɾ ə dɪstəns baɪ hɪmsɛlf, ði oʊɡiɝ cʊɾə pæs fəɹ ə tɔl mæn liɾɪŋ ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi hɔɹs, əɹ fəɹ ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi mæn liɾɪŋ ən ʌndɝ-saɪz hɔɹs. wɪð ði ʌðɝz ɪn ə laɪn bɪhaɪn ɪm tə ɡɪv pɝspɛktɪv, lɔɪəl lʊkt ɪɡzækli əz bɪɡ əz i wɑz, hæf əɡɛn əz tɔl əz ɛni mæn ʃəd bi. ðə mæn tʊk wʌn lʊk ænd, wɪð ə stʃɹæŋɡəl kɹaɪ, sɛɾ ɔf ɹʌnɪŋ, hɪz kloʊk flæpɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm.

That one man flicked his eyes at them, just like the others, already sinking back into his own thoughts when suddenly he stumbled and almost fell, turning himself back around to stare. There was only light enough to see shapes, but that was too much. Seen at a distance by himself, the Ogier could have passed for a tall man leading an ordinary horse, or for an ordinary man leading an under-sized horse. With the others in a line behind him to give perspective, Loial looked exactly as big as he was, half again as tall as any man should be. The man took one look and, with a strangled cry, set off running, his cloak flapping behind him.

ðəɹ wəd bi mɔɹ pipəl ɪn ðə stʃɹits sun - vɛɹi sun. ɹænd aɪɾ ə wʊmən hɝiɪŋ pæst ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə stʃɹit, siɪŋ nʌθɪŋ bʌt ðə peɪvmən ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ fit. mɔɹ pipəl tə noʊɾəs sun. ði istɝn skaɪ ɡɹu laɪɾɝ.

There would be more people in the streets soon - very soon. Rand eyed a woman hurrying past on the other side of the street, seeing nothing but the pavement in front of her feet. More people to notice soon. The eastern sky grew lighter.

"ðɛɹ," lɔɪəl ənaʊnst ət læst. "ɪɾ ɪz ʌndɝ ðɛɹ." ɪt wɑz ə ʃɑp i pɔɪntəd tə, stɪl kloʊz fəɹ ðə naɪt. ðə teɪbəlz aʊt fɹʌnt wɝ bɛɹ, ði ɔnɪŋz oʊvɝ əm ɹoʊld ʌp taɪt, ðə dɔɹ staʊtli ʃʌɾɝd. ðə wɪndoʊz əbʌv, wɛɹ ðə ʃɑpkipɝ lɪvd, wɝ stɪl dɑɹk.

"There," Loial announced at last. "It is under there." It was a shop he pointed to, still closed for the night. The tables out front were bare, the awnings over them rolled up tight, the door stoutly shuttered. The windows above, where the shopkeeper lived, were still dark.

"ʌndɝ?" mæt ɪkskleɪmd ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. "haʊ ɪn ðə laɪt kən wi - ?"

"Under?" Mat exclaimed incredulously. "How in the Light can we - ?"

mɔɪɹeɪn ɹeɪzd ə hæn ðət kʌɾ ɪm ɔf, ən moʊʃən fəɹ əm tə fɑloʊ hɝ ɪndə ði æli bɪsaɪd ðə ʃɑp. hɔɹsəz ən pipəl təɡɛðɝ, ðeɪ kɹaʊɾəd ði oʊpənɪŋ bɪtwin ðə tu bɪldɪŋz. ʃeɪɾɪd baɪ ðə wɔlz, ɪt wɑz dɑɹkɝ ðəɹ ðən ɑn ðə stʃɹit, nɪɹ tə fʊl naɪɾ əɡɛn.

Moiraine raised a hand that cut him off, and motioned for them to follow her into the alley beside the shop. Horses and people together, they crowded the opening between the two buildings. Shaded by the walls, it was darker there than on the street, near to full night again.

"ðɛɹ mʌs bi ə sɛlɝ dɔɹ," mɔɪɹeɪn mʌɾɝd. "ɑ, jɛs."

"There must be a cellar door," Moiraine muttered. "Ah, yes."

əbɹʌpli laɪt blɑsəmd. ə kuli ɡloʊɪŋ bɔl ðə saɪz ʌv ə mænz fɪs hʌŋ səspɛndəɾ oʊvɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz pɑm, muvɪŋ əz ʃi muvd əɹ hænd. ɹænd θɔt ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə mɛʒɝ ʌv wʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn θɹu ðəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn sim tə teɪk ɪɾ əz ə mæɾɝ ə kɔɹs. ʃi pʊɾ ɪt kloʊs tə ðə dɔɹz ʃi hæd faʊnd, slæntəɾ ɔlmoʊs flæt tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, wɪð ə hæsp hɛl baɪ θɪk boʊls ən ən aɪɝn lɑk bɪɡɝ ðən ɹændz hæn ən θɪk wɪð oʊld ɹʌst.

Abruptly light blossomed. A coolly glowing ball the size of a man's fist hung suspended over the Aes Sedai's palm, moving as she moved her hand. Rand thought that it was a measure of what they had been through that everyone seemed to take it as a matter of course. She put it close to the doors she had found, slanted almost flat to the ground, with a hasp held by thick bolts and an iron lock bigger than Rand's hand and thick with old rust.

lɔɪəl ɡeɪv ðə lɑk ə tʌɡ. "aɪ kən pʊl ɪɾ ɔf, hæsp ən ɔl, bʌɾ ɪɾəl meɪk ɪnʌf nɔɪz tə weɪk ðə hoʊl neɪbɝhʊd."

Loial gave the lock a tug. "I can pull it off, hasp and all, but it will make enough noise to wake the whole neighborhood."

"lɛɾ əs nɑt dæmədʒ ðə ɡʊdmənz pɹɑpɝɾi ɪf wi kən əvɔɪɾ ɪt." mɔɪɹeɪn stʌɾid ðə lɑk ɪntɛnli fəɹ ə moʊmənt. sʌɾənli ʃi ɡeɪv ðə ɹʌsti aɪɝn ə tæp wɪð əɹ stæf, ən ðə lɑk fɛl oʊpən nitli.

"Let us not damage the goodman's property if we can avoid it." Moiraine studied the lock intently for a moment. Suddenly she gave the rusty iron a tap with her staff, and the lock fell open neatly.

heɪstəli lɔɪəl əndɪd ðə lɑk ən swʌŋ ðə dɔɹz ʌp, pɹɑpɪŋ əm bæk. mɔɪɹeɪn wɛn daʊn ðə ɹæmp ðʌs ɹɪvild, laɪɾɪŋ əɹ weɪ wɪð ðə ɡloʊɪŋ bɔl. ɑldib stɛp dɛləkətli bɪhaɪn hɝ.

Hastily Loial undid the lock and swung the doors up, propping them back. Moiraine went down the ramp thus revealed, lighting her way with the glowing ball. Aldieb stepped delicately behind her.

"laɪt ðə læntɝnz ən kʌm daʊn," ʃi kɔl sɔfli. "ðɛɹ ɪz plɛnti ʌv ɹum. hɝi. ɪɾəl bi laɪɾ aʊt sun."

"Light the lanterns and come down," she called softly. "There is plenty of room. Hurry. It will be light out soon."

ɹænd hɝidli əntaɪd ðə poʊld læntɝnz ɔf ðə pæk hɔɹs, bʌɾ ivən bɪfɔɹ ðə fɝst wɑz lɪɾ i ɹilaɪzd i kəd si mæts fitʃɝz. pipəl wəd bi fɪlɪŋ ðə stʃɹits ɪn mɪnəts, ən ðə ʃɑpkipɝ wəd bi kʌmɪŋ daʊn tə oʊpən ʌp fəɹ bɪznəs, ɔl wʌndɝɪŋ waɪ ði æliweɪ wɑz kɹæm fʊl ə hɔɹsəz. mæt mʌɾɝd sʌmθɪŋ nɝvəsli əbaʊt teɪkɪŋ hɔɹsəz ɪndɔɹz, bʌt ɹænd wɑz ɡlæd tə liɾ ɪz daʊn ðə ɹæmp. mæt fɑloʊd, ɡɹʌmbəlɪŋ bʌt noʊ lɛs kwɪkli.

Rand hurriedly untied the poled lanterns off the pack horse, but even before the first was lit he realized he could see Mat's features. People would be filling the streets in minutes, and the shopkeeper would be coming down to open up for business, all wondering why the alleyway was crammed full of horses. Mat muttered something nervously about taking horses indoors, but Rand was glad to lead his down the ramp. Mat followed, grumbling but no less quickly.

ɹændz læntɝn swʌŋ ɑn ði ɛn ʌv ɪts poʊl, bʌmpɪŋ ðə silɪŋ ɪf i wɑz nɑt kɛɹfəl, ən niðɝ ɹɛd nɔɹ ðə pæk hɔɹs laɪk ðə ɹæmp. ðən i wɑz daʊn ən ɡɛɾɪŋ aʊɾ ə mæts weɪ. mɔɪɹeɪn lɛɾ əɹ floʊɾɪŋ laɪt daɪ, bʌɾ əz ðə ɹɛs dʒɔɪn ðɛm, ði æɾəd læntɝnz lɪt ði oʊpən speɪs.

Rand's lantern swung on the end of its pole, bumping the ceiling if he was not careful, and neither Red nor the pack horse liked the ramp. Then he was down and getting out of Mat's way. Moiraine let her floating light die, but as the rest joined them, the added lanterns lit the open space.

ðə sɛlɝ wɑz əz lɔŋ ən əz waɪɾ əz ðə bɪldɪŋ əbʌv, mʌtʃ ə ðə speɪs teɪkən ʌp baɪ bɹɪk kɑləmz, flɛɹɪŋ ʌp fɹəm nɛɹoʊ beɪsəz tə faɪv taɪmz əz bɪɡ ət ðə silɪŋ. ðə pleɪs simd meɪɾ ʌp fɹəm ə sɪɹiz ʌv ɑɹtʃəz. ðəɹ wɑz plɛnti ʌv ɹum, bʌt ɹænd stɪl fɛl kɹaʊɾəd. lɔɪəlz hɛd bɹʌʃt ðə silɪŋ. əz ðə ɹʌstəd lɑk hæd fɔɹtoʊld, ðə sɛlɝ hæd nɑt bɪn juzd ɪn ə lɔŋ taɪm. ðə flɔɹ wɑz bɛɹ ɪksɛp fəɹ ə fju bɹoʊkən bæɹəlz fɪld wɪð ɑdz ən ɛnz, ən ə θɪk leɪɝ ə dʌst. moʊts, stɝɾ ʌp baɪ soʊ mɛni fit, spɑɹkəld ɪn ðə læntɝn laɪt.

The cellar was as long and as wide as the building above, much of the space taken up by brick columns, flaring up from narrow bases to five times as big at the ceiling. The place seemed made up from a series of arches. There was plenty of room, but Rand still felt crowded. Loial's head brushed the ceiling. As the rusted lock had foretold, the cellar had not been used in a long time. The floor was bare except for a few broken barrels filled with odds and ends, and a thick layer of dust. Motes, stirred up by so many feet, sparkled in the lantern light.

læn wɑz læst ɪn, ən əz sun əz i hæd mændɑɹb daʊn ðə ɹæmp i klaɪm bæk tə pʊl ðə dɔɹz ʃʌt.

Lan was last in, and as soon as he had Mandarb down the ramp he climbed back to pull the doors shut.

"blʌɾ ən æʃəz," mæt ɡɹaʊld, "waɪ wəd ðeɪ bɪld wʌn ə ðiz ɡeɪts ɪn ə pleɪs laɪk ðɪs?"

"Blood and ashes," Mat growled, "why would they build one of these gates in a place like this?"

"ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ɔlweɪz laɪk ðɪs," lɔɪəl sɛd. hɪz ɹʌmbəlɪŋ vɔɪs ɛkoʊɾ ɪn ðə kævɝnəs speɪs. "nɑɾ ɔlweɪz. noʊ!" ði oʊɡiɝ wɑz æŋɡɹi, ɹænd ɹilaɪzd wɪð ə ʃɑk. "wʌns tʃɹiz stʊd hɪɹ. ɛvɹi kaɪndə tʃɹi ðət wəd ɡɹoʊ ɪn ðɪs pleɪs, ɛvɹi kaɪndə tʃɹi ðəɾ oʊɡiɝ kəd koʊks tə ɡɹoʊ hɪɹ. ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz, ə hʌnʒɹəd spænz haɪ. ʃeɪɾ ə bɹæntʃ, ən kul bɹizɪz tə kætʃ ðə smɛl ə lif ən flaʊɝ ən hoʊl ðə mɛmɹi ʌv ðə pis ə ðə stɛɾɪŋ. ɔl ðæt, mɝɾɝd fəɹ ðɪs!" hɪz fɪs θʌmpt ə kɑləm.

"It was not always like this," Loial said. His rumbling voice echoed in the cavernous space. "Not always. No!" The Ogier was angry, Rand realized with a shock. "Once trees stood here. Every kind of tree that would grow in this place, every kind of tree that Ogier could coax to grow here. The Great Trees, a hundred spans high. Shade of branch, and cool breezes to catch the smell of leaf and flower and hold the memory of the peace of the stedding. All that, murdered for this!" His fist thumped a column.

ðə kɑləm sim tə ʃeɪk ʌndɝ ðət bloʊ. ɹænd wɑz sɝɾən i hɝd bɹɪks kɹæk. wɔɾɝfɔlz ə dʒɹaɪ mɔɹɾɝ slɪd daʊn ðə kɑləm.

The column seemed to shake under that blow. Rand was certain he heard bricks crack. Waterfalls of dry mortar slid down the column.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɔlɹɛɾi woʊvən kænɑt bi əndʌn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd dʒɛnli. "ɪt wɪl nɑt meɪk ðə tʃɹiz ɡɹoʊ əɡɛn fəɹ jə tə bɹɪŋ ðə bɪldɪŋ daʊn ɑn əɹ hɛdz." lɔɪəlz dʒɹupɪŋ aɪbɹaʊz meɪɾ ɪm lʊk mɔɹ əbæʃt ðən ə hjumən feɪs kəɾ əv mænədʒd. "wɪð jəɹ hɛlp, lɔɪəl, pɝhæps wi kən kip ðə ɡɹoʊvz ðət stɪl stæn fɹəm fɔlɪŋ ʌndɝ ðə ʃædoʊ. juv bɹɔɾ əs tə wʌt wi sik."

"What is already woven cannot be undone," Moiraine said gently. "It will not make the trees grow again for you to bring the building down on our heads." Loial's drooping eyebrows made him look more abashed than a human face could have managed. "With your help, Loial, perhaps we can keep the groves that still stand from falling under the Shadow. You have brought us to what we seek."

əz ʃi muv tə wʌn ə ðə wɔlz, ɹænd ɹilaɪz ðət ðət wɔl wɑz dɪfɹən fɹəm ði ʌðɝz. ðeɪ wɝ ɔɹɾənɛɹi bɹɪk; ðɪs wɑz ɪntʃɹəkətli wɝk stoʊn, fænsɪfəl swɝlz ə livz ən vaɪnz, peɪl ivən ʌndɝ ɪts koʊɾ ə dʌst. ðə bɹɪk ən mɔɹɾɝ wɝ oʊld, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə stoʊn sɛɾ ɪt hæd stʊd ðəɹ lɔŋ, lɔŋ bɪfɔɹ ðə bɹɪk wɑz faɪɝd. leɪɾɝ bɪldɝz, ðɛmsɛlvz sɛntʃɝiz ɡɔn, hæɾ ɪnkɔɹpɝeɪɾəd wʌɾ ɔlɹɛɾi stʊd, ən stɪl leɪɾɝ mɛn hæd meɪɾ ɪt pɑɹɾ ʌv ə sɛlɝ.

As she moved to one of the walls, Rand realized that that wall was different from the others. They were ordinary brick; this was intricately worked stone, fanciful swirls of leaves and vines, pale even under its coat of dust. The brick and mortar were old, but something about the stone said it had stood there long, long before the brick was fired. Later builders, themselves centuries gone, had incorporated what already stood, and still later men had made it part of a cellar.

wʌn pɑɹɾ ə ðə kɑɹv stoʊn wɔl, ɹaɪɾ ɪn ðə sɛntɝ, wɑz mɔɹ ɪlæbɹət ðən ðə ɹɛst. əz wɛl dʌn əz ðə ɹɛst wɑz, ɪɾ əpɪɹɾ ə kɹud kɑpi ɪn kəmpɛɹəsən. wɝkt ɪn hɑɹd stoʊn, ðoʊz livz sim sɑft, kɑɾ ɪn wʌn fɹoʊzən moʊmən əz ə dʒɛntəl sʌmɝ bɹiz stɝd ðɛm. fəɹ ɔl ə ðæt, ðeɪ hæd ðə fil ʌv eɪdʒ, əz mʌtʃ ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ðə ɹɛst ə ðə stoʊn əz ðə ɹɛst wɑz oʊldɝ ðən ðə bɹɪk. ðəɾ oʊld ən mɔɹ. lɔɪəl lʊkt əɾ əm əz ɪf i wəd ɹæðɝ bi ɛniwɛɹ ɛls bʌt ðɛɹ, ivən aʊɾ ɪn ðə stʃɹits wɪð ənʌðɝ mɑb.

One part of the carved stone wall, right in the center, was more elaborate than the rest. As well done as the rest was, it appeared a crude copy in comparison. Worked in hard stone, those leaves seemed soft, caught in one frozen moment as a gentle summer breeze stirred them. For all of that, they had the feel of age, as much greater than the rest of the stone as the rest was older than the brick. That old and more. Loial looked at them as if he would rather be anywhere else but there, even out in the streets with another mob.

"ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə," mɔɪɹeɪn mɝmɝd, ɹɛstɪŋ əɹ hæn ɑn ə tʃɹɛfɔɪl lif ɪn ðə stoʊnwɝk. ɹænd skæn ðə kɑɹvɪŋ; ðət wɑz ði oʊnli lif ʌv ɪts kaɪn i kəd faɪnd. "ðə lif ə ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf ɪz ðə ki," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd, ən ðə lif keɪm əweɪ ɪn əɹ hænd.

"Avendesora," Moiraine murmured, resting her hand on a trefoil leaf in the stonework. Rand scanned the carving; that was the only leaf of its kind he could find. "The leaf of the Tree of Life is the key," the Aes Sedai said, and the leaf came away in her hand.

ɹænd blɪŋkt; fɹəm bɪhaɪn ɪm i hɝd ɡæsps. ðət lif hæd sim noʊ lɛs ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə wɔl ðən ɛni ʌðɝ. dʒʌst əz sɪmpli, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛɾ ɪɾ əɡɛns ðə pæɾɝn ə hændspæn loʊɝ. ðə θɹi-pɔɪntəd lif fɪt ðəɹ əz ɪf ðə speɪs hæd bɪn ɪntɛndəd fəɹ ɪt, ən wʌns mɔɹ ɪt wɑz ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə hoʊl. əz sun əz ɪt wɑz ɪn pleɪs ði ɪntaɪɝ neɪtʃɝ ə ðə sɛntʃɹəl stoʊnwɝk tʃeɪnʒd.

Rand blinked; from behind him he heard gasps. That leaf had seemed no less a part of the wall than any other. Just as simply, the Aes Sedai set it against the pattern a handspan lower. The three-pointed leaf fit there as if the space had been intended for it, and once more it was a part of the whole. As soon as it was in place the entire nature of the central stonework changed.

hi wɑz ʃʊɹ naʊ ðəɾ i kəd si ðə livz ɹʌfəl baɪ səm ənfɛl bɹiz; hi ɔlmoʊs θɔt ðeɪ wɝ vɝɾənt ʌndɝ ðə dʌst, ə tæpəstʃɹi ʌv θɪk spɹɪŋ ɡɹinɝi ðəɹ ɪn ðə læntɝn-lɪt sɛlɝ. ɔlmoʊst ɪmpɝsɛptɪbli ət fɝst, ə splɪɾ oʊpən ʌp ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ði eɪntʃən kɑɹvɪŋ, waɪɾənɪŋ əz ðə tu hævz sloʊli swʌŋ ɪndə ðə sɛlɝ əntɪl ðeɪ stʊd stʃɹeɪɾ aʊt. ðə bæks ə ðə ɡeɪts wɝ wɝkt əz ðə fɹʌns, ðə seɪm pɹəfjuʒən ə vaɪnz ən livz, ɔlmoʊst əlaɪv. bɪhaɪnd, wɛɹ ʃʊɾə bɪn dɝɾ əɹ ðə sɛlɝ ə ðə nɛks bɪldɪŋ, ə dʌl, ɹɪflɛktɪv ʃɪmɝɪŋ feɪnli kɑt ðɛɹ ɪmədʒəz.

He was sure now that he could see the leaves ruffled by some unfelt breeze; he almost thought they were verdant under the dust, a tapestry of thick spring greenery there in the lantern-lit cellar. Almost imperceptibly at first, a split opened up in the middle of the ancient carving, widening as the two halves slowly swung into the cellar until they stood straight out. The backs of the gates were worked as the fronts, the same profusion of vines and leaves, almost alive. Behind, where should have been dirt or the cellar of the next building, a dull, reflective shimmering faintly caught their images.

"aɪ hæv hɝd," lɔɪəl sɛd, hæf mɔɹnɪŋ, hæf fɪɹfəl, "ðæt wʌns ðə weɪɡeɪts ʃoʊn laɪk mɪɹɝz. wʌns, hu ɛntɝd ðə weɪz wɔk θɹu ðə sʌn ən ðə skaɪ. wʌns."

"I have heard," Loial said, half mourning, half fearful, "that once the Waygates shone like mirrors. Once, who entered the Ways walked through the sun and the sky. Once."

"wi hæv noʊ taɪm fəɹ weɪɾɪŋ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd.

"We have no time for waiting," Moiraine said.

læn wɛn pæs hɝ, liɾɪŋ mændɑɹb, poʊld læntɝn ɪn hænd. hɪz ʃæɾoʊi ɹəflɛkʃən əpɹoʊtʃt hɪm, liɾɪŋ ə ʃæɾoʊi hɔɹs. mæn ən ɹəflɛkʃən sim tə stɛp ɪndə itʃ ʌðɝ ət ðə ʃɪmɝɪŋ sɝfəs, ən boʊθ wɝ ɡɔn. fəɹ ə moʊmən ðə blæk stæljən bɔkt, ən əpɛɹənli kəntɪnjuəs ɹeɪn kənɛktɪŋ ɪm tə ðə dɪm ʃeɪp ə hɪz oʊn ɪmədʒ. ðə ɹeɪn taɪɾənd, ən ðə wɔɹhɔɹs, tu, vænɪʃt.

Lan went past her, leading Mandarb, poled lantern in hand. His shadowy reflection approached him, leading a shadowy horse. Man and reflection seemed to step into each other at the shimmering surface, and both were gone. For a moment the black stallion balked, an apparently continuous rein connecting him to the dim shape of his own image. The rein tightened, and the warhorse, too, vanished.

fəɹ ə mɪnəɾ ɛvɹiwʌn ɪn ðə sɛlɝ stʊd stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə weɪɡeɪt.

For a minute everyone in the cellar stood staring at the Waygate.

"hɝi," mɔɪɹeɪn ɝdʒd. "aɪ mʌs bi ðə læs θɹu. wi kænɑt liv ðɪs oʊpən fəɹ ɛniwʌn tə faɪn baɪ tʃæns. hɝi."

"Hurry," Moiraine urged. "I must be the last through. We cannot leave this open for anyone to find by chance. Hurry."

wɪð ə hɛvi saɪ lɔɪəl stʃɹoʊɾ ɪndə ðə ʃɪmɝ. tɔsɪŋ ɪts hɛd, hɪz bɪɡ hɔɹs tʃɹaɪd tə hoʊl bæk fɹəm ðə sɝfəs ən wɑz hɔl θɹu. ðeɪ wɝ ɡɔn əz kəmplitli əz ðə wɔɹɾɝ ən mændɑɹb.

With a heavy sigh Loial strode into the shimmer. Tossing its head, his big horse tried to hold back from the surface and was hauled through. They were gone as completely as the Warder and Mandarb.

hɛzɪɾəntli, ɹænd poʊkt ɪz læntɝn ət ðə weɪɡeɪt. ðə læntɝn sæŋk ɪndə ɪts ɹəflɛkʃən, ðə tu mɝdʒɪŋ əntɪl boʊθ wɝ ɡɔn. hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf kip ɑn wɔkɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə poʊl dɪsəpɪɹ ɪndə ɪtsɛlf ɪntʃ baɪ ɪntʃ, ən ðən i wɑz stɛpɪŋ ɪndə hɪmsɛlf, ɛntɝɪŋ ðə ɡeɪt. hɪz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən. sʌmθɪŋ aɪsi slɪɾ əlɔŋ ɪz skɪn, əz ɪf i wɝ pæsɪŋ θɹu ə wɔl ə koʊld wɔɾɝ. taɪm stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt; ðə koʊld ɛnvɛləpt wʌn hɛɹ əɾ ə taɪm, ʃɪvɝɾ oʊvɝ ɪz kloʊðz θɹɛd baɪ θɹɛd.

Hesitantly, Rand poked his lantern at the Waygate. The lantern sank into its reflection, the two merging until both were gone. He made himself keep on walking forward, watching the pole disappear into itself inch by inch, and then he was stepping into himself, entering the gate. His mouth fell open. Something icy slid along his skin, as if he were passing through a wall of cold water. Time stretched out; the cold enveloped one hair at a time, shivered over his clothes thread by thread.

əbɹʌpli ðə tʃɪl bɝs laɪk ə bʌbəl, ən i pɔz tə kætʃ ɪz bɹɛθ. hi wɑz ɪnsaɪd ðə weɪz. dʒʌst əhɛd læn ən lɔɪəl weɪɾəd peɪʃənli baɪ ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz. ɔl ɝaʊn əm wɑz blæknəs ðət sim tə stʃɹɛtʃ ɑn fɝɛvɝ. ðɛɹ læntɝnz meɪɾ ə smɔl pul ə laɪɾ ɝaʊn ðɛm, tu smɔl, əz ɪf sʌmθɪŋ pɹɛs bæk ðə laɪt, əɹ eɪɾ ɪt.

Abruptly the chill burst like a bubble, and he paused to catch his breath. He was inside the Ways. Just ahead Lan and Loial waited patiently by their horses. All around them was blackness that seemed to stretch on forever. Their lanterns made a small pool of light around them, too small, as if something pressed back the light, or ate it.

ʌv ə sʌɾən æŋkʃəs, hi dʒɝkt əɾ ɪz ɹeɪnz. ɹɛɾ ən ðə pæk hɔɹs keɪm lipɪŋ θɹu, nɪɹli nɑkɪŋ ɪm daʊn. stʌmbəlɪŋ, hi kɑt hɪmsɛlf ən hɝid tə ðə wɔɹɾɝ ən ði oʊɡiɝ, pʊlɪŋ ðə nɝvəs hɔɹsəz bɪhaɪn hɪm. ði ænəməlz wɪkɝd sɔfli. ivən mændɑɹb əpɪɹd tə teɪk səm kʌmfɝt fɹəm ðə pɹɛzəns ʌv ʌðɝ hɔɹsəz.

Of a sudden anxious, he jerked at his reins. Red and the pack horse came leaping through, nearly knocking him down. Stumbling, he caught himself and hurried to the Warder and the Ogier, pulling the nervous horses behind him. The animals whickered softly. Even Mandarb appeared to take some comfort from the presence of other horses.

"ɡoʊ izi wən jə pæs θɹu ə weɪɡeɪt, ɹænd," lɔɪəl kɑʃənd. "θɪŋz ɑɹ . . . dɪfɹən ɪnsaɪd ðə weɪz ðən aʊt. lʊk."

"Go easy when you pass through a Waygate, Rand," Loial cautioned. "Things are . . . different inside the Ways than out. Look."

hi lʊk bæk ðə weɪ ði oʊɡiɝ pɔɪntəd, θɪŋkɪŋ tə si ðə seɪm dʌl ʃɪmɝ. ɪnstɛɾ i kəd si ɪndə ðə sɛlɝ, əz ɪf θɹu ə lɑɹdʒ pis ə smoʊkt ɡlæs sɛɾ ɪn ðə blæknəs. dɪstɝbɪŋli ðə dɑɹknəs ɝaʊn ðə wɪndoʊ ɪndə ðə sɛlɝ ɡeɪv ə sɛns ə dɛpθ, əz ðoʊ ði oʊpənɪŋ stʊɾ əloʊn wɪð nʌθɪŋ ɝaʊn əɹ bɪhaɪn ɪt bʌt ðə dɑɹk. hi sɛɾ əz mʌtʃ wɪð ə ʃeɪki læf, bʌt lɔɪəl tʊk ɪm sɪɹiəsli.

He looked back the way the Ogier pointed, thinking to see the same dull shimmer. Instead he could see into the cellar, as if through a large piece of smoked glass set in the blackness. Disturbingly the darkness around the window into the cellar gave a sense of depth, as though the opening stood alone with nothing around or behind it but the dark. He said as much with a shaky laugh, but Loial took him seriously.

"ju kəd wɔk ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊn ɪt, ən jə wəd nɑt si ə θɪŋ fɹəm ði ʌðɝ saɪd. aɪ wəd nɑɾ ædvaɪz ɪt, ðoʊ. ðə bʊks ɑɹən vɛɹi klɪɹ əbaʊt wʌt laɪz bɪhaɪn ðə weɪɡeɪts. aɪ θɪŋk jə kəd bɪkʌm lɔs ðɛɹ, ən nɛvɝ faɪn jəɹ weɪ aʊt."

"You could walk all the way around it, and you would not see a thing from the other side. I would not advise it, though. The books aren't very clear about what lies behind the Waygates. I think you could become lost there, and never find your way out."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ ən tʃɹaɪd tə kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾ ɑn ðə weɪɡeɪɾ ɪtsɛlf ɹæðɝ ðən wʌt leɪ bɪhaɪn ɪt, bʌt ðət wɑz dʒʌst əz dɪstɝbɪŋ ɪn ɪts oʊn fæʃən. ɪf ðəɹ hæd bɪn ɛniθɪŋ tə lʊk əɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹknəs bɪsaɪdz ðə weɪɡeɪt, hi wʊɾə lʊkt əɾ ɪt. ɪn ðə sɛlɝ, θɹu ðə smoʊki dɪmnəs, mɔɪɹeɪn ən ði ʌðɝz wɝ pleɪn ɪnʌf, bʌt ðeɪ muvd əz ɪf ɪn ə dʒɹim. ɛvɹi blɪŋk ʌv ən aɪ simd ə dɪlɪbɝɪt, ɪɡzædʒɝeɪɾəd dʒɛstʃɝ. mæt wɑz meɪkɪŋ ɪz weɪ tə ðə weɪɡeɪɾ əz ðoʊ wɔkɪŋ θɹu klɪɹ dʒɛli, hɪz lɛɡz simɪŋ tə swɪm fɔɹwɝd.

Rand shook his head and tried to concentrate on the Waygate itself rather than what lay behind it, but that was just as disturbing in its own fashion. If there had been anything to look at in the darkness besides the Waygate, he would have looked at it. In the cellar, through the smoky dimness, Moiraine and the others were plain enough, but they moved as if in a dream. Every blink of an eye seemed a deliberate, exaggerated gesture. Mat was making his way to the Waygate as though walking through clear jelly, his legs seeming to swim forward.

"ðə wil tɝnz fæstɝ ɪn ðə weɪz," lɔɪəl ɪkspleɪnd. hi lʊkt ət ðə dɑɹknəs sɝaʊndɪŋ ðɛm, ən ɪz hɛd sʌŋk ɪn bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. "nʌn əlaɪv noʊ mɔɹ ðən fɹæɡməns. aɪ fɪɹ wʌɾ aɪ doʊnt noʊ əbaʊt ðə weɪz, ɹænd."

"The Wheel turns faster in the Ways," Loial explained. He looked at the darkness surrounding them, and his head sunk in between his shoulders. "None alive know more than fragments. I fear what I don't know about the Ways, Rand."

"ðə dɑɹk wʌn," læn sɛd, "kænɑt bi dɪfiɾəd wɪθaʊt tʃænsɪŋ ɹɪsks. bʌt wəɹ əlaɪv ət ðɪs moʊmənt, ən bɪfɔɹ əs ɪz ðə hoʊp ə ɹɪmeɪnɪŋ əlaɪv. də nɑt sɝɛndɝ bɪfɔɹ jə ɑɹ biɾən, oʊɡiɝ."

"The Dark One," Lan said, "cannot be defeated without chancing risks. But we are alive at this moment, and before us is the hope of remaining alive. Do not surrender before you are beaten, Ogier."

"ju wəd nɑt spik soʊ kɑnfəɾəntli ɪf jə hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn ɪn ðə weɪz." ðə nɔɹməl dɪstən θʌndɝ ə lɔɪəlz vɔɪs wɑz mjuɾɪd. hi stɛɹɾ ət ðə blæknəs əz ɪf i sɔ θɪŋz ðɛɹ. "aɪ nɛvɝ əv bɪfɔɹ, iðɝ, bʌɾ aɪv sin oʊɡiɝ u hæv bɪn θɹu ə weɪɡeɪɾ ən kʌm aʊɾ əɡɛn. jə wəd nɑt spik soʊ ɪf jə hæd."

"You would not speak so confidently if you had ever been in the Ways." The normal distant thunder of Loial's voice was muted. He stared at the blackness as if he saw things there. "I never have before, either, but I've seen Ogier who have been through a Waygate and come out again. You would not speak so if you had."

mæt stɛp θɹu ðə ɡeɪɾ ən ɹiɡeɪnd nɔɹməl spid. fəɹ ən ɪnstən i stɛɹɾ ət ðə simɪŋli ɛnləs dɑɹknəs, ðən keɪm ɹʌnɪŋ tə dʒɔɪn ðɛm, hɪz læntɝn bɑbɪŋ ɑn ɪts poʊl, hɪz hɔɹs lipɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm, ɔlmoʊst sɛndɪŋ ɪm spɹɔlɪŋ. wʌn baɪ wʌn ði ʌðɝz pæs θɹu, pɛɹɪn ən ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv, itʃ pɔzɪŋ ɪn ʃɑk saɪləns bɪfɔɹ hɝiɪŋ tə dʒɔɪn ðə ɹɛst. itʃ læntɝn ɛnlɑɹdʒ ðə pul ə laɪt, bʌt nɑɾ əz mʌtʃ əz ɪt ʃəd hæv. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ðə dɑɹk bɪkeɪm dɛnsɝ ðə mɔɹ laɪt ðəɹ wɑz, θɪkənɪŋ əz ɪt fɔɾ əɡɛns biɪŋ dɪmɪnɪʃt.

Mat stepped through the gate and regained normal speed. For an instant he stared at the seemingly endless darkness, then came running to join them, his lantern bobbing on its pole, his horse leaping behind him, almost sending him sprawling. One by one the others passed through, Perrin and Egwene and Nynaeve, each pausing in shocked silence before hurrying to join the rest. Each lantern enlarged the pool of light, but not as much as it should have. It was as if the dark became denser the more light there was, thickening as it fought against being diminished.

ðət wɑz nɑɾ ə laɪn ə ɹizənɪŋ ɹænd wɑntəd tə fɑloʊ. ɪt wɑz bæɾ ɪnʌf dʒʌs biɪŋ ðəɹ wɪθaʊt ɡɪvɪŋ ðə dɑɹknəs ə wɪl ʌv ɪts oʊn. ɛvɹiwʌn sim tə fil ði əpɹɛsɪvnəs, ðoʊ. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ ɹaɪ kɑmɛns fɹəm mæt hɪɹ, ən ɛɡwin lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi wɪʃt ʃi kəd ɹiθɪŋk əɹ dɪsɪʒən tə kʌm. ðeɪ ɔl saɪlənli wɑtʃt ðə weɪɡeɪt, ðət læst wɪndoʊ ɪndə ðə wɝl ðeɪ nu.

That was not a line of reasoning Rand wanted to follow. It was bad enough just being there without giving the darkness a will of its own. Everyone seemed to feel the oppressiveness, though. There were no wry comments from Mat here, and Egwene looked as if she wished she could rethink her decision to come. They all silently watched the Waygate, that last window into the world they knew.

faɪnəli oʊnli mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz lɛft ɪn ðə sɛlɝ, dɪmli lɪt baɪ ðə læntɝn ʃi hæd teɪkən. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stɪl muvd ɪn ðət dʒɹimlaɪk weɪ. hɝ hæn kɹɛpt əz ɪt faʊn ðə lif ʌv ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə. ɪt wɑz loʊkeɪɾəd loʊɝ ɪn ðə stoʊnwɝk ɑn ðɪs saɪd, ɹænd sɔ, dʒʌst wɛɹ ʃi hæd pleɪst ɪɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ. plʌkɪŋ ɪt fɹi, ʃi pʊɾ ɪt bæk ɪn ði ɝɪdʒənəl pəzɪʃən. hi wʌndɝd sʌɾənli ɪf ðə lif ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd hæd muv bæk, tu.
