Finally only Moiraine was left in the cellar, dimly lit by the lantern she had taken. The Aes Sedai still moved in that dreamlike way. Her hand crept as it found the leaf of Avendesora. It was located lower in the stonework on this side, Rand saw, just where she had placed it on the other. Plucking it free, she put it back in the original position. He wondered suddenly if the leaf on the other side had moved back, too.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ keɪm θɹu, liɾɪŋ ɑldib, əz ðə stoʊn ɡeɪts sloʊli, sloʊli bɪɡæn kloʊzɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɝ. ʃi keɪm tə dʒɔɪn ðɛm, ðə laɪɾ ə hɝ læntɝn livɪŋ ðə ɡeɪts bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ wɝ ʃʌt. blæknəs swɑloʊd ðə nɛɹoʊɪŋ vju ʌv ðə sɛlɝ. ɪn ðə kənstʃɹeɪn laɪɾ ə ðɛɹ læntɝnz, blæknəs sɝaʊndəɾ əm toʊɾəli.

The Aes Sedai came through, leading Aldieb, as the stone gates slowly, slowly began closing behind her. She came to join them, the light of her lantern leaving the gates before they were shut. Blackness swallowed the narrowing view of the cellar. In the constrained light of their lanterns, blackness surrounded them totally.

sʌɾənli ɪt simd əz ɪf ðə læntɝnz wɝ ði oʊnli laɪt lɛft ɪn ðə wɝld. ɹænd ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz dʒæmd ʃoʊldɝ-tə-ʃoʊldɝ ɪn bɪtwin pɛɹɪn ən ɛɡwin. ɛɡwin ɡeɪv ɪm ə waɪd-aɪd lʊk ən pɹɛs kloʊsɝ, ən pɛɹɪn meɪd noʊ muv tə ɡɪv ɪm ɹum. ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ kʌmfɝɾɪŋ əbaʊt tʌtʃɪŋ ənʌðɝ hjumən biɪŋ wən ðə hoʊl wɝl hæd dʒʌs bɪn swɑloʊɾ ʌp baɪ dɑɹk. ivən ðə hɔɹsəz sim tə fil ðə weɪz pʊʃɪŋ əm ɪndə ə taɪɾɝ ən taɪɾɝ nɑt.

Suddenly it seemed as if the lanterns were the only light left in the world. Rand realized that he was jammed shoulder-to-shoulder in between Perrin and Egwene. Egwene gave him a wide-eyed look and pressed closer, and Perrin made no move to give him room. There was something comforting about touching another human being when the whole world had just been swallowed up by dark. Even the horses seemed to feel the Ways pushing them into a tighter and tighter knot.

aʊtwɝdli ʌnkənsɝnd, mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn swʌŋ ɪndə ðɛɹ sæɾəlz, ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ lin fɔɹwɝd, ɑɹmz ɹɛstɪŋ ɑn əɹ kɑɹv stæf əkɹɔs ðə haɪ pɑməl ə hɝ sæɾəl. "wi mʌs bi ɑn əɹ weɪ, lɔɪəl."

Outwardly unconcerned, Moiraine and Lan swung into their saddles, and the Aes Sedai leaned forward, arms resting on her carved staff across the high pommel of her saddle. "We must be on our way, Loial."

lɔɪəl ɡeɪv ə stɑɹt, ən nɑɾəd vɪɡɝəsli. "jɛs. jɛs, ɛɛs sədaɪ, jə ɑɹ ɹaɪt. nɑɾ ə mɪnət lɔŋɡɝ ðən nid bi." hi pɔɪntəd tə ə bɹɔd stʃɹɪp ʌv waɪt ɹʌnɪŋ ʌndɝ ðɛɹ fit, ən ɹænd stɛpt əweɪ fɹəm ɪt heɪstəli. ɔl ðə tu ɹɪvɝz foʊk dɪd. ɹænd θɔt ðə flɔɹ hæd bɪn smuð wʌns, bʌt ðə smuðnəs wɑz pɪɾəd naʊ, əz ɪf ðə stoʊn hæd ðə pɑks. ðə waɪt laɪn wɑz bɹoʊkən ɪn sɛvɹəl pleɪsəz. "ðɪs lidz fɹəm ðə weɪɡeɪt tə ðə fɝst ɡaɪɾɪŋ. fɹəm ðɛɹ. . . ." lɔɪəl lʊkt ɝaʊn æŋkʃəsli, ðən skɹæmbəld ɑntu hɪz hɔɹs wɪð nʌn ə ðə ɹɪlʌktəns i hæd ʃoʊn ɝliɝ. ðə hɔɹs wɔɹ ðə bɪɡəst sæɾəl ðə hɛd ɡɹum hæd bɪn eɪbəl tə faɪnd, bʌt lɔɪəl fɪld ɪt fɹəm pɑməl tə kæntəl. hɪz fit hʌŋ daʊn ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ɔlmoʊs tə ði ænəməlz niz. "nɑɾ ə mɪnət lɔŋɡɝ ðən nid bi," hi mʌɾɝd. ɹɪlʌktənli ði ʌðɝz maʊntəd.

Loial gave a start, and nodded vigorously. "Yes. Yes, Aes Sedai, you are right. Not a minute longer than need be." He pointed to a broad strip of white running under their feet, and Rand stepped away from it hastily. All the Two Rivers folk did. Rand thought the floor had been smooth once, but the smoothness was pitted now, as if the stone had the pox. The white line was broken in several places. "This leads from the Waygate to the first Guiding. From there. . . ." Loial looked around anxiously, then scrambled onto his horse with none of the reluctance he had shown earlier. The horse wore the biggest saddle the head groom had been able to find, but Loial filled it from pommel to cantle. His feet hung down on either side almost to the animal's knees. "Not a minute longer than need be," he muttered. Reluctantly the others mounted.

mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn ɹoʊɾ ɑn iðɝ saɪɾ ə ði oʊɡiɝ, fɑloʊɪŋ ðə waɪt laɪn θɹu ðə dɑɹk. ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls kɹaʊɾəd ɪn bɪhaɪn əz kloʊs əz ðeɪ kəd ɡɛt, ðə læntɝnz bɑbɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛɹ hɛdz. ðə læntɝnz ʃʊɾə ɡɪvən ɪnʌf laɪt tə fɪl ə haʊs, bʌt tɛn fiɾ əweɪ fɹəm əm ɪt stɑpt. ðə blæknəs stɑpt ɪɾ əz ɪf ɪt hæd stʃɹʌk ə wɔl. ðə kɹik ə sæɾəlz ən klɪk ə hɔɹs ʃuz ɑn stoʊn sim tə tʃɹævəl oʊnli tə ði ɛdʒ ə laɪt.

Moiraine and Lan rode on either side of the Ogier, following the white line through the dark. Everyone else crowded in behind as close as they could get, the lanterns bobbing over their heads. The lanterns should have given enough light to fill a house, but ten feet away from them it stopped. The blackness stopped it as if it had struck a wall. The creak of saddles and click of horse shoes on stone seemed to travel only to the edge of light.

ɹændz hæn kɛp dʒɹɪftɪŋ tə hɪz sɔɹd. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðəɾ i θɔt ðəɹ wɑz ɛniθɪŋ aʊt ðəɹ əɡɛnst wɪtʃ i kəd juz ðə sɔɹd tə dɪfɛn hɪmsɛlf; ɪt dɪd nɑt sim əz ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ɛniwɛɹ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə bi. ðə bʌbəl ə laɪɾ ɝaʊn əm kəɾ əz wɛl əv bɪn ə keɪv sɝaʊndəd baɪ stoʊn, kəmplitli sɝaʊndəd, wɪð noʊ weɪ aʊt. ðə hɔɹsəz maɪɾ əv bɪn wɔkɪŋ ə tʃɹɛdmɪl fəɹ ðə tʃeɪnʒ ɝaʊn ðɛm. hi ɡɹɪp ðə hɪlt əz ɪf ðə pɹɛʃɝ ə hɪz hæn ðəɹ kəd pɹɛs əweɪ ðə stoʊn i fɛlt weɪɪŋ daʊn ɑn hɪm. tʌtʃɪŋ ðə sɔɹd, hi kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ tæmz titʃɪŋ. fəɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪl i kəd faɪn ðə kɑm ə ðə vɔɪd. bʌt ðə weɪɾ ɔlweɪz ɹɪtɝnd, kəmpɹɛsɪŋ ðə vɔɪɾ əntɪl ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə kævɝn ɪnsaɪɾ ɪz maɪnd, ən i hæd tə stɑɹɾ oʊvɝ əɡɛn, tʌtʃɪŋ tæmz sɔɹd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ.

Rand's hand kept drifting to his sword. It was not that he thought there was anything out there against which he could use the sword to defend himself; it did not seem as if there was anywhere for something to be. The bubble of light around them could as well have been a cave surrounded by stone, completely surrounded, with no way out. The horses might have been walking a treadmill for the change around them. He gripped the hilt as if the pressure of his hand there could press away the stone he felt weighing down on him. Touching the sword, he could remember Tam's teaching. For a little while he could find the calm of the void. But the weight always returned, compressing the void until it was only a cavern inside his mind, and he had to start over again, touching Tam's sword to remember.

ɪt wɑz ə ɹɪlif wən sʌmθɪŋ dɪd tʃeɪnʒ, ivən ɪf ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə tɔl slæb ə stoʊn, stændɪŋ ɑn ɛnd, ðəɾ əpɪɹɾ aʊɾ ə ðə dɑɹk bɪfɔɹ ðɛm, ðə bɹɔd waɪt laɪn stɑpɪŋ əɾ ɪts beɪs. sɪnwəs kɝvz ə mɛɾəl ɪnleɪd ðə waɪd sɝfəs, ɡɹeɪsfəl laɪnz ðət veɪɡli ɹimaɪndəd ɹænd ə vaɪnz ən livz. dɪskʌlɝd pɑks mɑɹk stoʊn ən mɛɾəl əlaɪk.

It was a relief when something did change, even if it was only a tall slab of stone, standing on end, that appeared out of the dark before them, the broad white line stopping at its base. Sinuous curves of metal inlaid the wide surface, graceful lines that vaguely reminded Rand of vines and leaves. Discolored pocks marked stone and metal alike.

"ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ," lɔɪəl sɛd, ən lin aʊɾ ə hɪz sæɾəl tə fɹaʊn ət ðə kɝsɪv mɛɾəl ɪnleɪz.

"The Guiding," Loial said, and leaned out of his saddle to frown at the cursive metal inlays.

"oʊɡiɝ skɹɪpt," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "bʌt soʊ bɹoʊkən aɪ kən bɛɹli meɪk aʊt wʌɾ ɪt sɛz."

"Ogier script," Moiraine said, "but so broken I can barely make out what it says."

"aɪ hɑɹdli kæn, iðɝ," lɔɪəl sɛd, "bʌɾ ɪnʌf tə noʊ wi ɡoʊ ðɪs weɪ." hi tɝn ɪz hɔɹs əsaɪd fɹəm ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ.

"I hardly can, either," Loial said, "but enough to know we go this way." He turned his horse aside from the Guiding.

ði ɛdʒəz ə ðɛɹ laɪt kɑɾ ʌðɝ stoʊnwɝks, wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi stoʊn-wɔl bɹɪdʒəz ɑɹsɪŋ ɔf ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs, ən dʒɛnli sloʊpɪŋ ɹæmps, wɪθaʊt ɹeɪlɪŋz ʌv ɛni kaɪnd, liɾɪŋ ʌp ən daʊn. bɪtwin ðə bɹɪdʒəz ən ðə ɹæmps ɹæn ə tʃɛst-haɪ bəlʌstʃɹeɪd, haʊɛvɝ, əz ðoʊ fɔlɪŋ wɑz ə deɪnʒɝ ðəɹ əɾ ɛni ɹeɪt. pleɪn waɪt stoʊn meɪd ðə bəlʌstʃɹeɪd, ɪn sɪmpəl kɝvz ən ɹaʊnz fɪɾəd təɡɛðɝ ɪn kɑmplɛks pæɾɝnz. sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɔl ʌv ɪt simd ɔlmoʊs fəmɪljɝ tə ɹænd, bʌɾ i nu ɪt hæd tə bi hɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən ɡɹoʊpɪŋ fəɹ ɛniθɪŋ fəmɪljɝ wɛɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ.

The edges of their light caught other stoneworks, what appeared to be stone-walled bridges arcing off into the darkness, and gently sloping ramps, without railings of any kind, leading up and down. Between the bridges and the ramps ran a chest-high balustrade, however, as though falling was a danger there at any rate. Plain white stone made the balustrade, in simple curves and rounds fitted together in complex patterns. Something about all of it seemed almost familiar to Rand, but he knew it had to be his imagination groping for anything familiar where everything was strange.

ət ðə fʊɾ ʌv wʌn ə ðə bɹɪdʒəz lɔɪəl pɔz tə ɹid ðə sɪŋɡəl laɪn ɑn ðə nɛɹoʊ kɑləm stoʊn ðɛɹ. nɑɾɪŋ, hi ɹoʊɾ ʌp ɑntu ðə bɹɪdʒ. "ðɪs ɪz ðə fɝs bɹɪdʒ ʌv əɹ pæθ," hi sɛɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ.

At the foot of one of the bridges Loial paused to read the single line on the narrow column stone there. Nodding, he rode up onto the bridge. "This is the first bridge of our path," he said over his shoulder.

ɹænd wʌndɝd wʌt hɛl ðə bɹɪdʒ ʌp. ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz meɪɾ ə ɡɹɪɾi saʊnd, əz ɪf bɪts ə stoʊn fleɪkt ɔf əɾ ɛvɹi stɛp. ɛvɹiθɪŋ i kəd si wɑz kʌvɝd wɪð ʃæloʊ hoʊlz, səm taɪni pɪnpɹɪks, ʌðɝz ʃæloʊ, ɹʌf-ɛdʒ kɹeɪɾɝz ə stʃɹaɪɾ əkɹɔs, əz ɪf ðəɹ hæd bɪn ə ɹeɪn ʌv æsəd, əɹ ðə stoʊn wɑz ɹɑɾɪŋ. ðə ɡɑɹdwəl ʃoʊd kɹæks ən hoʊlz, tu. ɪn pleɪsəz ɪt wɑz ɡɔn ɔltəɡɛðɝ fəɹ əz mʌtʃ əz ə spæn. fəɹ ɔl i nu ðə bɹɪdʒ kəd bi sɑləd stoʊn ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə sɛntɝ ə ði ɝθ, bʌt wʌɾ i sɔ meɪɾ ɪm hoʊp ɪt wəd stæn lɔŋ ɪnʌf fəɹ əm tə ɹitʃ ði ʌðɝ ɛnd. wɛɹɛvɝ ðəɾ ɪz.

Rand wondered what held the bridge up. The horses' hooves made a gritty sound, as if bits of stone flaked off at every step. Everything he could see was covered with shallow holes, some tiny pinpricks, others shallow, rough-edged craters a stride across, as if there had been a rain of acid, or the stone was rotting. The guardwall showed cracks and holes, too. In places it was gone altogether for as much as a span. For all he knew the bridge could be solid stone all the way to the center of the earth, but what he saw made him hope it would stand long enough for them to reach the other end. Wherever that is.

ðə bɹɪdʒ dɪɾ ɛnd, ɪvɛntʃəwəli, ɪn ə pleɪs ðət lʊk noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ɪts bɪɡɪnɪŋ. ɔl ɹænd kəd si wɑz wʌt ðɛɹ lɪɾəl pul ə laɪt tʌtʃt, bʌɾ i hæd ði ɪmpɹɛʃən ðəɾ ɪt wɑz ə lɑɹdʒ speɪs, laɪk ə flæt-tɑp hɪl, wɪð bɹɪdʒəz ən ɹæmps livɪŋ ɔl ɝaʊn ɪt. ən aɪlənd, lɔɪəl kɔld ɪt. ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ skɹɪpt-kʌvɝd ɡaɪɾɪŋ - ɹænd pleɪst ɪɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ði aɪlənd, wɪð noʊ weɪ ʌv noʊɪŋ ɪf i wɑz ɹaɪɾ əɹ nɑt. lɔɪəl ɹɛd, ðən tʊk əm ʌp wʌn ə ðə ɹæmps, kɝvɪŋ ʌp ən ʌp.

The bridge did end, eventually, in a place that looked no different from its beginning. All Rand could see was what their little pool of light touched, but he had the impression that it was a large space, like a flat-topped hill, with bridges and ramps leaving all around it. An Island, Loial called it. There was another script-covered Guiding - Rand placed it in the middle of the Island, with no way of knowing if he was right or not. Loial read, then took them up one of the ramps, curving up and up.

æftɝ ən ɪntɝmənəbəl klaɪm, kɝvɪŋ kəntɪnjuəsli, ðə ɹæmp lɛɾ ɔf ɑntu ənʌðɝ aɪlən dʒʌs laɪk ðə wʌn wɛɹ ɪt hæd bɪɡʌn. ɹænd tʃɹaɪd tə ɪmædʒən ðə kɝv ə ðə ɹæmp ən ɡeɪv ʌp. ðɪs aɪlən kæn bi ɹaɪɾ ɑn tɑp ə ði ʌðɝ wʌn. ɪt kæn bi.

After an interminable climb, curving continuously, the ramp let off onto another Island just like the one where it had begun. Rand tried to imagine the curve of the ramp and gave up. This Island can't be right on top of the other one. It can't be.

lɔɪəl kənsʌltəd jɛɾ ənʌðɝ slæb fɪld wɪð oʊɡiɝ skɹɪpt, faʊn ənʌðɝ saɪnpoʊs kɑləm, lɛɾ əm ɑntu ənʌðɝ bɹɪdʒ. ɹænd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hæɾ ɛni aɪdiə ɪn wʌt dɝɛkʃən ðeɪ wɝ tʃɹævlɪŋ.

Loial consulted yet another slab filled with Ogier script, found another signpost column, led them onto another bridge. Rand no longer had any idea in what direction they were traveling.

ɪn ðɛɹ hʌɾəl ə laɪɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk, wʌn bɹɪdʒ wɑz ɪɡzækli laɪk ənʌðɝ, ɪksɛp ðət səm hæd bɹeɪks ɪn ðə ɡɑɹdwɔlz ən səm dɪd nɑt. oʊnli ðə dɪɡɹi ʌv dæmədʒ tə ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋz ɡeɪv ɛni dɪfɝəns tə ði aɪlənz. ɹænd lɔs tʃɹæk ə taɪm; hi wɑz nɑɾ ivən ʃʊɹ haʊ mɛni bɹɪdʒəz ðeɪ hæd kɹɔst əɹ haʊ mɛni ɹæmps ðeɪ hæd tʃɹævəld. ðə wɔɹɾɝ mʌst əv hæɾ ə klɑk ɪn ɪz hɛd, ðoʊ. dʒʌst wən ɹænd fɛl ðə fɝst stɝ ə hʌŋɡɝ, læn ənaʊns kwaɪətli ðəɾ ɪt wɑz mɪddeɪ ən dɪsmaʊntɪd tə pɑɹsəl aʊt bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz ən dʒɹaɪd mit fɹəm ðə pæk hɔɹs. pɛɹɪn wɑz liɾɪŋ ði ænəməl baɪ ðət taɪm. ðeɪ wɝ ɑn ən aɪlənd, ən lɔɪəl wɑz bɪzəli dəsaɪfɝɪŋ ðə dɝɛkʃənz ɑn ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ.

In their huddle of light in the dark, one bridge was exactly like another, except that some had breaks in the guardwalls and some did not. Only the degree of damage to the Guidings gave any difference to the Islands. Rand lost track of time; he was not even sure how many bridges they had crossed or how many ramps they had traveled. The Warder must have had a clock in his head, though. Just when Rand felt the first stir of hunger, Lan announced quietly that it was midday and dismounted to parcel out bread and cheese and dried meat from the pack horse. Perrin was leading the animal by that time. They were on an Island, and Loial was busily deciphering the directions on the Guiding.

mæt stɑɹɾəd tə klaɪm daʊn fɹəm ɪz sæɾəl, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "taɪm ɪz tu væljəbəl ɪn ðə weɪz tə weɪst. fəɹ ʌs, mʌtʃ tu væljəbəl. wɪl stɑp wən ɪts taɪm tə slip." læn wɑz ɔlɹɛɾi bæk ɑn mændɑɹb.

Mat started to climb down from his saddle, but Moiraine said, "Time is too valuable in the Ways to waste. For us, much too valuable. We will stop when it is time to sleep." Lan was already back on Mandarb.

ɹændz æpətaɪt slɪpt ət ðə θɔɾ ə slipɪŋ ɪn ðə weɪz. ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz naɪt ðɛɹ, bʌt nɑt ðə kaɪndə naɪt fəɹ slipɪŋ. hi eɪt waɪl i ɹoʊd, ðoʊ, laɪk ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. ɪt wɑz ən ɑkwɝɾ əfɛɹ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə dʒʌɡəl ɪz fud, ðə læntɝn poʊl, ən ɪz ɹeɪnz, bʌt fəɹ ɔl ə hɪz ɪmædʒən læk ʌv æpətaɪɾ i lɪk ðə læs kɹʌmz ə bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz ɔf ɪz hænz wən i wɑz dʌn, ən θɔt fɑnli ʌv mɔɹ. hi ivən bɪɡæn tə θɪŋk ðə weɪz wɝ nɑt soʊ bæd, nɑt nɪɹli əz bæɾ əz lɔɪəl meɪɾ aʊt. ðeɪ maɪɾ əv ðə hɛvi fil ə ði aʊɝ bɪfɔɹ ə stɔɹm, bʌt nʌθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd. nʌθɪŋ hæpənd. ðə weɪz wɝ ɔlmoʊs bɔɹɪŋ.

Rand's appetite slipped at the thought of sleeping in the Ways. It was always night there, but not the kind of night for sleeping. He ate while he rode, though, like everyone else. It was an awkward affair, trying to juggle his food, the lantern pole, and his reins, but for all of his imagined lack of appetite he licked the last crumbs of bread and cheese off his hands when he was done, and thought fondly of more. He even began to think the Ways were not so bad, not nearly as bad as Loial made out. They might have the heavy feel of the hour before a storm, but nothing changed. Nothing happened. The Ways were almost boring.

ðən ðə saɪləns wɑz bɹoʊkən baɪ ə stɑɹɾəld ɡɹʌn fɹəm lɔɪəl. ɹænd stʊɾ ɪn ɪz stɝəps tə pɪɹ pæs ði oʊɡiɝ, ən swɑloʊd hɑɹɾ ət wʌɾ i sɔ. ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə bɹɪdʒ, ən oʊnli ə fju fiɾ əhɛɾ ə lɔɪəl ðə bɹɪdʒ ɛndəɾ ɪn ə dʒæɡd ɡæp.

Then the silence was broken by a startled grunt from Loial. Rand stood in his stirrups to peer past the Ogier, and swallowed hard at what he saw. They were in the middle of a bridge, and only a few feet ahead of Loial the bridge ended in a jagged gap.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾifaɪv


CHAPTER 45

wʌt fɑloʊz ɪn ʃædoʊ


What Follows in Shadow

ðə laɪɾ ə ðɛɹ læntɝnz stʃɹɛtʃt dʒʌs fɑɹ ɪnʌf tə tʌtʃ ði ʌðɝ saɪd, θɹʌstɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə dɑɹk laɪk ə dʒaɪəns bɹoʊkən tiθ. lɔɪəlz hɔɹs stæmpt ə huf nɝvəsli, ən ə lus stoʊn fɛl əweɪ ɪndə ðə dɛd blæk bɪloʊ. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ɛni saʊn ʌv ɪt stʃɹaɪkɪŋ bɑɾəm, ɹænd nɛvɝ hɝɾ ɪt.

The light of their lanterns stretched just far enough to touch the other side, thrusting out of the dark like a giant's broken teeth. Loial's horse stamped a hoof nervously, and a loose stone fell away into the dead black below. If there was any sound of it striking bottom, Rand never heard it.

hi ɛdʒd ɹɛd kloʊsɝ tə ðə ɡæp. əz fɑɹ daʊn əz i kəd θɹʌst ɪz læntɝn ɑn ɪts poʊl, ðəɹ wɑz nʌθɪŋ. blæknəs bɪloʊ əz blæknəs əbʌv, ʃɪɹɪŋ ɔf ðə laɪt. ɪf ðəɹ wɑz ə bɑɾəm, ɪt kəd bi ə θaʊzən fit daʊn. əɹ nɛvɝ. bʌɾ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd, hi kəd si wʌt wɑz ʌndɝ ðə bɹɪdʒ, hoʊldɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp. nʌθɪŋ. lɛs ðən ə spæn ɪn θɪknəs, ən æbsəlutli nʌθɪŋ ʌndɝniθ.

He edged Red closer to the gap. As far down as he could thrust his lantern on its pole, there was nothing. Blackness below as blackness above, shearing off the light. If there was a bottom, it could be a thousand feet down. Or never. But on the other side, he could see what was under the bridge, holding it up. Nothing. Less than a span in thickness, and absolutely nothing underneath.

əbɹʌpli ðə stoʊn ʌndɝ ɪz fit simd əz θɪn əz peɪpɝ, ən ði ɛnləs dʒɹɑp oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ pʊld ət hɪm. ðə læntɝn ən poʊl sim sʌɾənli hɛvi ɪnʌf tə pʊl ɪm ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə sæɾəl. hɛd spɪnɪŋ, hi bæk ðə beɪ əweɪ fɹəm ði əbɪs əz kɔʃəsli əz i hæɾ əpɹoʊtʃt.

Abruptly the stone under his feet seemed as thin as paper, and the endless drop over the edge pulled at him. The lantern and pole seemed suddenly heavy enough to pull him right out of the saddle. Head spinning, he backed the bay away from the abyss as cautiously as he had approached.

"ɪz ɪt tə ðɪs juv bɹɔɾ ʌs, ɛɛs sədaɪ?" nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ɔl ðɪs dʒʌs tə faɪn aʊt wɪv tə ɡoʊ bæk tə keɪɛmlɪn æftɝ ɔl?"

"Is it to this you've brought us, Aes Sedai?" Nynaeve said. "All this just to find out we have to go back to Caemlyn after all?"

"wi də nɑɾ əv tə ɡoʊ bæk," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "nɑɾ ɔl ðə weɪ tə keɪɛmlɪn. ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni pæðz əlɔŋ ðə weɪz tə ɛni pleɪs. wi niɾ oʊnli ɡoʊ bæk fɑɹ ɪnʌf fəɹ lɔɪəl tə faɪn ənʌðɝ pæθ ðət wɪl lid tə fæl dæɹə. lɔɪəl? lɔɪəl!"

"We do not have to go back," Moiraine said. "Not all the way to Caemlyn. There are many paths along the Ways to any place. We need only go back far enough for Loial to find another path that will lead to Fal Dara. Loial? Loial!"

ði oʊɡiɝ pʊl hɪmsɛlf əweɪ fɹəm stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə ɡæp wɪð ə vɪzəbəl ɛfɝt. "wʌt? oʊ. jɛs, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ kən faɪn ənʌðɝ pæθ. aɪ hæd." hɪz aɪz dʒɹɪftəd bæk tə ðə kæzəm, ən ɪz ɪɹz twɪtʃt. "aɪ hæd nɑt dʒɹim ðə dəkeɪ hæd ɡɔn soʊ fɑɹ. ɪf ðə bɹɪdʒəz ðɛmsɛlvz ɑɹ bɹeɪkɪŋ, ɪt meɪ bi ðəɾ aɪ kænɑt faɪn ðə pæθ jə wɑnt. ɪt meɪ bi ðəɾ aɪ kænɑt faɪn ə pæθ bæk, iðɝ. ðə bɹɪdʒəz kəd bi fɔlɪŋ bɪhaɪn əs ivən naʊ."

The Ogier pulled himself away from staring at the gap with a visible effort. "What? Oh. Yes, Aes Sedai. I can find another path. I had." His eyes drifted back to the chasm, and his ears twitched. "I had not dreamed the decay had gone so far. If the bridges themselves are breaking, it may be that I cannot find the path you want. It may be that I cannot find a path back, either. The bridges could be falling behind us even now."

"ðɛɹ əz tə bi ə weɪ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, hɪz vɔɪs flæt. hɪz aɪz sim tə ɡæðɝ ðə laɪt, tə ɡloʊ ɡoʊldən. ə wʊlf ət beɪ, ɹænd θɔt, stɑɹɾəld. ðæts wʌɾ i lʊks laɪk.

"There has to be a way," Perrin said, his voice flat. His eyes seemed to gather the light, to glow golden. A wolf at bay, Rand thought, startled. That's what he looks like.

"ɪt wɪl bi əz ðə wil wivz," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt bɪliv ðə dəkeɪ ɪz əz fæst əz jə fɪɹ. lʊk ət ðə stoʊn, lɔɪəl. ivən aɪ kən tɛl ðət ðɪs ɪz ən oʊl bɹeɪk."

"It will be as the Wheel weaves," Moiraine said, "but I do not believe the decay is as fast as you fear. Look at the stone, Loial. Even I can tell that this is an old break."

"jɛs," lɔɪəl sɛd sloʊli. "jɛs, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ kən si ɪt. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ ɹeɪn əɹ wɪn hɪɹ, bʌt ðət stoʊn əz bɪn ɪn ði ɛɹ fəɹ tɛn jɪɹz, ət list." hi nɑɾəd wɪð ə ɹɪlivd ɡɹɪn, soʊ hæpi wɪð ðə dɪskʌvɝi ðət fəɹ ə moʊmən i sim tə fɝɡɛɾ ɪz fɪɹ. ðən i lʊkt ɝaʊn ən ʃɹʌɡd ənkʌmftəbli. "aɪ kəd faɪn ʌðɝ pæðz mɔɹ izəli ðən mæfəl dɑɾɝɑnɛl. tɑɹ vəlɑn, fəɹ ɪnstəns? əɹ stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ. ɪts oʊnli θɹi bɹɪdʒəz tə stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ fɹəm ðə læst aɪlənd. aɪ səpoʊz ði ɛldɝz wɑnə tɔk tə mi baɪ ðɪs taɪm."

"Yes," Loial said slowly. "Yes, Aes Sedai. I can see it. There is no rain or wind here, but that stone has been in the air for ten years, at least." He nodded with a relieved grin, so happy with the discovery that for a moment he seemed to forget his fear. Then he looked around and shrugged uncomfortably. "I could find other paths more easily than Mafal Dadaranell. Tar Valon, for instance? Or Stedding Shangtai. It's only three bridges to Stedding Shangtai from the last Island. I suppose the Elders want to talk to me by this time."

"fæl dæɹə, lɔɪəl," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd fɝmli. "ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld laɪz bɪɑn fæl dæɹə, ən wi mʌst ɹitʃ ði aɪ."

"Fal Dara, Loial," Moiraine said firmly. "The Eye of the World lies beyond Fal Dara, and we must reach the Eye."

"fæl dæɹə," ði oʊɡiɝ əɡɹid ɹɪlʌktənli.

"Fal Dara," the Ogier agreed reluctantly.

bæk ət ði aɪlən lɔɪəl pɔɹɾ oʊvɝ ðə skɹɪpt-kʌvɝd slæb ɪntɛnli, dʒɹupɪŋ aɪbɹaʊz dʒɹɔn daʊn əz i mʌɾɝd hæf tə hɪmsɛlf. sun i wɑz tɔkɪŋ kəmplitli tə hɪmsɛlf, fəɹ i dʒɹɑpt ɪndə ði oʊɡiɝ læŋɡwədʒ. ðəɾ ɪnflɛktəd tʌŋ saʊndəd laɪk dip-vɔɪs bɝdz sɪŋɪŋ. ɪt simd ɑd tə ɹænd ðəɾ ə pipəl soʊ bɪɡ hæd sətʃ ə mjuzɪkəl læŋɡwədʒ.

Back at the Island Loial pored over the script-covered slab intently, drooping eyebrows drawn down as he muttered half to himself. Soon he was talking completely to himself, for he dropped into the Ogier language. That inflected tongue sounded like deep-voiced birds singing. It seemed odd to Rand that a people so big had such a musical language.

faɪnəli ði oʊɡiɝ nɑɾəd. əz i lɛɾ əm tə ðə tʃoʊzən bɹɪdʒ, hi tɝn tə pɪɹ fɔɹlɔɹnli ət ðə saɪnpoʊs bɪsaɪɾ ənʌðɝ. "θɹi kɹɔsɪŋz tə stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ." hi saɪd. bʌɾ i tʊk əm ɑn pæst wɪθaʊt stɑpɪŋ ən tɝn ɑntu ðə θɝd bɹɪdʒ bɪɑnd. hi lʊk bæk ɹɪɡɹɛtfəli əz ðeɪ stɑɹɾəd əkɹɔs, ðoʊ ðə bɹɪdʒ tə hɪz hoʊm wɑz hɪɾən ɪn ðə dɑɹk.

Finally the Ogier nodded. As he led them to the chosen bridge, he turned to peer forlornly at the signpost beside another. "Three crossings to Stedding Shangtai." He sighed. But he took them on past without stopping and turned onto the third bridge beyond. He looked back regretfully as they started across, though the bridge to his home was hidden in the dark.

ɹænd tʊk ðə beɪ ʌp bɪsaɪd ði oʊɡiɝ. "wɛn ðɪs ɪz oʊvɝ, lɔɪəl, jə ʃoʊ mi jəɹ stɛɾɪŋ, ən əl ʃoʊ jə ɛmənz fild. noʊ weɪz, ðoʊ. wɪl wɔk, əɹ ɹaɪd, ɪf ɪt teɪks ɔl sʌmɝ."

Rand took the bay up beside the Ogier. "When this is over, Loial, you show me your stedding, and I'll show you Emond's Field. No Ways, though. We'll walk, or ride, if it takes all summer."

"ju bɪliv ɪɾəl ɛvɝ bi oʊvɝ, ɹænd?"

"You believe it will ever be over, Rand?"

hi fɹaʊn ət ði oʊɡiɝ. "ju sɛɾ ɪt wəd teɪk tu deɪz tə ɹitʃ fæl dæɹə."

He frowned at the Ogier. "You said it would take two days to reach Fal Dara."

"nɑt ðə weɪz, ɹænd. ɔl ðə ɹɛst." lɔɪəl lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, tɔkɪŋ sɔfli wɪð læn əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd saɪd-baɪ-saɪd. "wʌt meɪks jə bɪliv ɪɾəl ɛvɝ bi oʊvɝ?"

"Not the Ways, Rand. All the rest." Loial looked over his shoulder at the Aes Sedai, talking softly with Lan as they rode side-by-side. "What makes you believe it will ever be over?"

ðə bɹɪdʒəz ən ɹæmps lɛɾ ʌp ən daʊn ən əkɹɔs. səmtaɪmz ə waɪt laɪn ɹæn ɔf ɪndə ðə dɑɹk fɹəm ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ, dʒʌs laɪk ðə laɪn ðeɪ hæd fɑloʊd fɹəm ðə weɪɡeɪɾ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ɹænd sɔ ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn u aɪd ðoʊz laɪnz kjʊɹiəsli, ən ə lɪɾəl wɪsfəli. nɪneɪiv, pɛɹɪn, mæt, ən ivən ɛɡwin lɛf ðə laɪnz ɹɪlʌktənli. ðəɹ wɑz ə weɪɡeɪɾ ət ði ʌðɝ ɛn ʌv itʃ ə ðɛm, ə ɡeɪt bæk ɪndə ðə wɝld, wɛɹ ðəɹ wɑz skaɪ ən sʌn ən wɪnd. ivən ðə wɪnd wʊɾə bɪn wɛlkəm. liv əm ðeɪ dɪd, ʌndɝ ði ɛɛs sədaɪz ʃɑɹp aɪ. bʌt ɹænd wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn tə lʊk bæk ivən æftɝ dɑɹk swɑloʊɾ aɪlən ən ɡaɪɾɪŋ ən laɪn.

The bridges and ramps led up and down and across. Sometimes a white line ran off into the dark from the Guiding, just like the line they had followed from the Waygate in Caemlyn. Rand saw that he was not the only one who eyed those lines curiously, and a little wistfully. Nynaeve, Perrin, Mat, and even Egwene left the lines reluctantly. There was a Waygate at the other end of each of them, a gate back into the world, where there was sky and sun and wind. Even the wind would have been welcome. Leave them they did, under the Aes Sedai's sharp eye. But Rand was not the only one to look back even after dark swallowed Island and Guiding and line.

ɹænd wɑz jɔnɪŋ baɪ ðə taɪm mɔɪɹeɪn ənaʊns ðət ðeɪ wəd stɑp fəɹ ðə naɪɾ ɑn wʌn ə ði aɪlənz. mæt lʊkt ət ðə blæknəs ɔl ɝaʊn əm ən snɪkɝd laʊdli, bʌɾ i ɡɑt daʊn əz kwɪkli əz ɛniwʌn ɛls. læn ən ðə bɔɪz ənsæɾəld ən hɑbəl ðə hɔɹsəz waɪl nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin sɛɾ ʌp ə smɔl ɔɪl stoʊv tə meɪk ti. lʊkɪŋ laɪk ðə beɪs ʌv ə læntɝn, ɪt wɑz wʌt læn sɛd wɔɹɾɝz juzd ɪn ðə blaɪt, wɛɹ ðə wʊd kəd bi deɪnʒɝəs tə bɝn. ðə wɔɹɾɝ pɹədus tʃɹaɪpɑd lɛɡz fɹəm ðə bæskəts ðeɪ tʊk ɔf ðə pæk hɔɹs, soʊ ðə læntɝn poʊlz kəd bi sɛɾ ɪn ə sɝkəl ɝaʊn ðɛɹ kæmpsaɪt.

Rand was yawning by the time Moiraine announced that they would stop for the night on one of the Islands. Mat looked at the blackness all around them and snickered loudly, but he got down as quickly as anyone else. Lan and the boys unsaddled and hobbled the horses while Nynaeve and Egwene set up a small oil stove to make tea. Looking like the base of a lantern, it was what Lan said Warders used in the Blight, where the wood could be dangerous to burn. The Warder produced tripod legs from the baskets they took off the pack horse, so the lantern poles could be set in a circle around their campsite.

lɔɪəl ɪɡzæmən ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən dʒɹɑp daʊn kɹɑslɛɡd ən ɹʌbd ə hæn əkɹɔs ðə dʌsti, pɑkmɑɹk stoʊn. "wʌns θɪŋz ɡɹu ɑn ði aɪlənz," hi sɛd sædli. "ɔl ðə bʊks tɛl ʌv ɪt. ðəɹ wɑz ɡɹin ɡɹæs tə slip ɑn, sɑft əz ɛni fɛðɝ bɛd. fɹut tʃɹiz tə spaɪs ðə fud jud bɹɔt wɪð ən æpəl əɹ ə pɛɹ əɹ ə bɛlfɹut, swiɾ ən kɹɪsp ən dʒusi wʌtɛvɝ ðə taɪm ə jɪɹ aʊtsaɪd."

Loial examined the Guiding for a moment, then dropped down crosslegged and rubbed a hand across the dusty, pockmarked stone. "Once things grew on the Islands," he said sadly. "All the books tell of it. There was green grass to sleep on, soft as any feather bed. Fruit trees to spice the food you'd brought with an apple or a pear or a bellfruit, sweet and crisp and juicy Whatever the time of year outside."

"nʌθɪŋ tə hʌnt," pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld, ðən lʊk sɝpɹaɪz ðəɾ i hæd spoʊkən.

"Nothing to hunt," Perrin growled, then looked surprised that he had spoken.

ɛɡwin hændəd lɔɪəl ə kʌp ə ti. hi hɛld ɪt wɪθaʊt dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ, stɛɹɪŋ əɾ ɪɾ əz ɪf i kəd faɪn ðə fɹut tʃɹiz ɪn ɪts dɛpθs.

Egwene handed Loial a cup of tea. He held it without drinking, staring at it as if he could find the fruit trees in its depths.

"ɑɹən jə gɑnə sɛt wɔɹdz?" nɪneɪiv æsk mɔɪɹeɪn. "ʃʊɹli ðəɹ mʌs bi wɝs ðən ɹæts ɪn ðɪs. ivən ɪf aɪ hævən sin ɛniθɪŋ, aɪ kən stɪl fil."

"Aren't you going to set wards?" Nynaeve asked Moiraine. "Surely there must be worse than rats in this. Even if I haven't seen anything, I can still feel."

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɹʌbd əɹ fɪŋɡɝz əɡɛnst əɹ pɑmz dɪsteɪsfəli. "ju fil ðə teɪnt, ðə kɝʌpʃən ə ðə paʊɝ ðət meɪd ðə weɪz. əl nɑt juz ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪn ðə weɪz ənlɛs aɪ mʌst. ðə teɪn ɪz soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðət wʌtɛvɝ aɪ tʃɹaɪd tə də wəd ʃʊɹli bi kɝʌptɪd."

The Aes Sedai rubbed her fingers against her palms distastefully. "You feel the taint, the corruption of the Power that made the Ways. I will not use the One Power in the Ways unless I must. The taint is so strong that Whatever I tried to do would surely be corrupted."

ðət meɪɾ ɛvɹiwʌn əz saɪlən əz lɔɪəl. læn sɛɾəld daʊn tə hɪz mil məθɑɾɪkəli, əz ɪf i wɝ stoʊkɪŋ ə faɪɝ, ðə fud lɛs ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən fjulɪŋ ɪz bɑɾi. mɔɪɹeɪn eɪt wɛl, tu, ən əz tɪɾəli əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ nɑt skwɑɾɪŋ ɑn bɛɹ stoʊn kwaɪt lɪɾɝəli ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə noʊwɛɹ, bʌt ɹænd oʊnli pɪkt əɾ ɪz fud. ðə taɪni fleɪm ə ði ɔɪl stoʊv ɡeɪv dʒʌst ɪnʌf hit tə bɔɪl wɔɾɝ, bʌɾ i kɹaʊtʃt təwɔɹɾ ɪɾ əz ɪf i kəd soʊk ʌp wɔɹmθ. hɪz ʃoʊldɝz bɹʌʃt mæt ən pɛɹɪn. ðeɪ ɔl meɪɾ ə taɪt sɝkəl ɝaʊn ðə stoʊv. mæt hɛld ɪz bɹɛɾ ən miɾ ən tʃiz fɝɡɑɾən ɪn ɪz hænz, ən pɛɹɪn sɛɾ ɪz tɪn pleɪt daʊn æftɝ oʊnli ə fju baɪts. ðə mud bɪkeɪm mɔɹ ən mɔɹ ɡlʌm, ən ɛvɹiwʌn lʊk daʊn, əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðə dɑɹk ɝaʊn ðɛm.

That made everyone as silent as Loial. Lan settled down to his meal methodically, as if he were stoking a fire, the food less important than fueling his body. Moiraine ate well, too, and as tidily as if they were not squatting on bare stone quite literally in the middle of nowhere, but Rand only picked at his food. The tiny flame of the oil stove gave just enough heat to boil water, but he crouched toward it as if he could soak up warmth. His shoulders brushed Mat and Perrin. They all made a tight circle around the stove. Mat held his bread and meat and cheese forgotten in his hands, and Perrin set his tin plate down after only a few bites. The mood became more and more glum, and everyone looked down, avoiding the dark around them.

mɔɪɹeɪn stʌɾid əm əz ʃi eɪt. faɪnəli ʃi pʊɾ əɹ pleɪɾ əsaɪɾ ən pæɾəd əɹ lɪps wɪð ə næpkɪn. "aɪ kən tɛl jə wʌn tʃɪɹfəl θɪŋ. aɪ də nɑt θɪŋk tɑm mɛɹɪlɪn ɪz dɛd."

Moiraine studied them as she ate. Finally she put her plate aside and patted her lips with a napkin. "I can tell you one cheerful thing. I do not think Thom Merrilin is dead."

ɹænd lʊkt əɾ əɹ ʃɑɹpli. "bʌt ðə feɪd."

Rand looked at her sharply. "But the Fade."

"mæt toʊl mi wʌt hæpən ɪn waɪtbɹɪdʒ," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd. "pipəl ðəɹ mɛnʃən ə ɡlimən, bʌt ðeɪ sɛd nʌθɪŋ ə hɪm daɪɪŋ. ðeɪ wəd hæv, aɪ θɪŋk, ɪf ə ɡlimən hæd bɪn kɪld. waɪtbɹɪdʒ ɪz nɑt soʊ bɪɡ əz fəɹ ə ɡlimən tə bi ə smɔl θɪŋ. ən tɑm ɪz ə pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn ðət wivz ɪtsɛlf ɝaʊn jə θɹi. tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt ə pɑɹt, aɪ bɪliv, tə bi kʌɾ ɔf jɛt."

"Mat told me what happened in Whitebridge," the Aes Sedai said. "People there mentioned a gleeman, but they said nothing of him dying. They would have, I think, if a gleeman had been killed. Whitebridge is not so big as for a gleeman to be a small thing. And Thom is a part of the Pattern that weaves itself around you three. Too important a part, I believe, to be cut off yet."

tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt? ɹænd θɔt. haʊ kəd mɔɪɹeɪn noʊ? "mɪn? ʃi sɔ sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt tɑm?"

Too important? Rand thought. How could Moiraine know? "Min? She saw something about Thom?"

"ʃi sɔ ə ɡɹeɪt dil," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd ɹaɪli. "əbaʊɾ ɔl ə ju. aɪ wɪʃ aɪ kəɾ ʌndɝstæn hæf ʌv wʌt ʃi sɔ, bʌɾ ivən ʃi dʌz nɑt. oʊl bæɹiɝz feɪl. bʌt wɛðɝ wʌt mɪn dʌz ɪz oʊld əɹ nu, ʃi siz tʃɹu. jəɹ feɪts ɑɹ baʊn təɡɛðɝ. tɑm mɛɹɪlɪnz, tu."

"She saw a great deal," Moiraine said wryly. "About all of you. I wish I could understand half of what she saw, but even she does not. Old barriers fail. But whether what Min does is old or new, she sees true. Your fates are bound together. Thom Merrilin's, too."

nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ə dɪsmɪsɪv snɪf ən pɔɹd hɝsɛlf ənʌðɝ kʌp ə ti.

Nynaeve gave a dismissive sniff and poured herself another cup of tea.

"aɪ doʊn si haʊ ʃi sɔ ɛniθɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɛni ʌv ʌs," mæt sɛd wɪð ə ɡɹɪn. "æz aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪt, ʃi spɛn moʊst ə hɝ taɪm lʊkɪŋ ət ɹænd."

"I don't see how she saw anything about any of us," Mat said with a grin. "As I remember it, she spent most of her time looking at Rand."

ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ. "oʊ? jə dɪdn tɛl mi ðæt, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ."

Egwene raised an eyebrow. "Oh? You didn't tell me that, Moiraine Sedai."

ɹænd ɡlænst ət hɝ. ʃi wɑz nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, bʌɾ əɹ toʊn hæd bɪn tu kɛɹfəli nutʃɹəl. "aɪ tɔk tə hɝ wʌns," hi sɛd. "ʃi dʒɹɛsəz laɪk ə bɔɪ, ən əɹ hɛɹ ɪz əz ʃɔɹɾ əz maɪn."

Rand glanced at her. She was not looking at him, but her tone had been too carefully neutral. "I talked to her once," he said. "She dresses like a boy, and her hair is as short as mine."

"ju tɔk tə hɝ. wʌns." ɛɡwin nɑɾəd sloʊli. stɪl nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ kʌp tə hɝ lɪps.

"You talked to her. Once." Egwene nodded slowly. Still not looking at him, she raised her cup to her lips.

"mɪn wɑz dʒʌst sʌmbɑɾi hu wɝkt ət ði ɪn ɪn bɛɹlən," pɛɹɪn sɛd. "nɑt laɪk ɛɹæm."

"Min was just somebody who worked at the inn in Baerlon," Perrin said. "Not like Aram."

ɛɡwin tʃoʊkt ɑn əɹ ti. "tu hɑt," ʃi mʌɾɝd.

Egwene choked on her tea. "Too hot," she muttered.

"huz ɛɹæm?" ɹænd æskt. pɛɹɪn smaɪld, mʌtʃ laɪk mæts smaɪl ɪn ði oʊl deɪz wən i wɑz ʌp tə mɪstʃəf, ən hɪd bɪhaɪn ɪz kʌp.

"Who's Aram?" Rand asked. Perrin smiled, much like Mat's smile in the old days when he was up to mischief, and hid behind his cup.

"wʌn ə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl," ɛɡwin sɛd kæʒəwəli, bʌt ɹɛd spɑts blumd ɪn əɹ tʃiks.

"One of the Traveling People," Egwene said casually, but red spots bloomed in her cheeks.

"wʌn ə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl," pɛɹɪn sɛd blænli. "hi dænsəz. laɪk ə bɝd. wɑzn ðət wʌt jə sɛd, ɛɡwin? ɪt wɑz laɪk flaɪɪŋ wɪð ə bɝd?"

"One of the Traveling People," Perrin said blandly. "He dances. Like a bird. Wasn't that what you said, Egwene? It was like flying with a bird?"

ɛɡwin sɛɾ əɹ kʌp daʊn dɪlɪbɝətli. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ ɪf ɛniwʌn ɛls ɪz taɪɝd, bʌɾ aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ tə slip."

Egwene set her cup down deliberately. "I don't know if anyone else is tired, but I'm going to sleep."

əz ʃi ɹoʊl hɝsɛlf ʌp ɪn əɹ blæŋkəts, pɛɹɪn ɹitʃt oʊvɝ tə nʌdʒ ɹænd ɪn ðə ɹɪbz ən wɪŋkt. ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɡɹɪnɪŋ bæk. bɝn mi, ɪf aɪ dɪdn kʌm aʊt bɛs fəɹ ə tʃeɪnʒ. aɪ wɪʃ aɪ nu əz mʌtʃ əbaʊt wɪmən əz pɛɹɪn.

As she rolled herself up in her blankets, Perrin reached over to nudge Rand in the ribs and winked. Rand found himself grinning back. Burn me, if I didn't come out best for a change. I wish I knew as much about women as Perrin.

"meɪbi, ɹænd," mæt sɛd slaɪli, "ju ɔt tə tɛl ɛɡwin əbaʊt fɑɹmɝ ɡɹɪnwɛlz dɔɾɝ, ɛls." ɛɡwin lɪftəɾ əɹ hɛd tə stɛɹ fɝst ət mæt, ðən ət hɪm.

"Maybe, Rand," Mat said slyly, "you ought to tell Egwene about Farmer Grinwell's daughter, Else." Egwene lifted her head to stare first at Mat, then at him.

hi heɪstəli ɡɑɾ ʌp tə fɛtʃ ɪz oʊn blæŋkəts. "slip saʊnz ɡʊd tə mi ɹaɪt naʊ."

He hastily got up to fetch his own blankets. "Sleep sounds good to me right now."

ɔl ði ɛmənz fil pipəl bɪɡæn sikɪŋ ðɛɹ blæŋkəts ðɛn, ən lɔɪəl, tu. mɔɪɹeɪn sæt sɪpɪŋ əɹ ti. ən læn. ðə wɔɹɾɝ dɪd nɑt lʊk əz ɪf i ɛvɝ ɪntɛndəd tə slip, əɹ niɾəd tə.

All the Emond's Field people began seeking their blankets then, and Loial, too. Moiraine sat sipping her tea. And Lan. The Warder did not look as if he ever intended to sleep, or needed to.

ivən ɹoʊld ʌp fəɹ slip, noʊ wʌn wɑntəd tə ɡɛt vɛɹi fɑɹ fɹəm ði ʌðɝz. ðeɪ meɪɾ ə smɔl sɝkəl ə blæŋkət-kʌvɝd maʊnz ɹaɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə stoʊv, ɔlmoʊs tʌtʃɪŋ wʌn ənʌðɝ.

Even rolled up for sleep, no one wanted to get very far from the others. They made a small circle of blanket-covered mounds right around the stove, almost touching one another.

"ɹænd," mæt wɪspɝd, "wɑz ðəɹ ɛniθɪŋ bɪtwin jə ən mɪn? aɪ bɛɹli ɡɑɾ ə lʊk ət hɝ. ʃi wɑz pɹɪɾi, bʌt ʃi mʌs bi nɪɹli əz oʊld əz nɪneɪiv."

"Rand," Mat whispered, "was there anything between you and Min? I barely got a look at her. She was pretty, but she must be nearly as old as Nynaeve."

"wʌɾ əbaʊt ðɪs ɛls?" pɛɹɪn æɾəd fɹəm ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə hɪm. "ʃi pɹɪɾi?"

"What about this Else?" Perrin added from the other side of him. "She pretty?"

"blʌɾ ən æʃəz," hi mʌmbəld, "kæn aɪ ivən tɔk tə ə ɡɝl? jə tu ɑɹ əz bæɾ əz ɛɡwin."

"Blood and ashes," he mumbled, "can't I even talk to a girl? You two are as bad as Egwene."

"æz ðə wɪzdəm wəd seɪ," mæt tʃaɪɾɪd mɑkəŋli, "wɑtʃ jəɹ tʌŋ. wɛl, ɪf jə woʊn tɔk əbaʊɾ ɪt, aɪm gɑnə ɡɛt səm slip."

"As the Wisdom would say," Mat chided mockingly, "watch your tongue. Well, if you won't talk about it, I'm going to get some sleep."

"ɡʊd," ɹænd ɡɹʌmbəld. "ðæts ðə fɝs disən θɪŋ juv sɛd."

"Good," Rand grumbled. "That's the first decent thing you've said."

slip wɑz nɑɾ izəli kʌm baɪ, ðoʊ. ðə stoʊn wɑz hɑɹd, haʊɛvɝ ɹænd leɪ, ən i kəd fil ðə pɪts θɹu hɪz blæŋkət. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ weɪ tə ɪmædʒən i wɑz ɛniwɛɹ bʌɾ ɪn ðə weɪz, meɪd baɪ ðə mɛn u hæd bɹoʊkən ðə wɝld, teɪntɪd baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. hi kɛpt pɪktʃɝɪŋ ðə bɹoʊkən bɹɪdʒ, ən ðə nʌθɪŋ ʌndɝ ɪt.

Sleep was not easily come by, though. The stone was hard, however Rand lay, and he could feel the pits through his blanket. There was no way to imagine he was anywhere but in the Ways, made by the men who had broken the world, tainted by the Dark One. He kept picturing the broken bridge, and the nothing under it.

wən i tɝnd wʌn weɪ hi faʊn mæt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm; lʊkɪŋ θɹu hɪm, ɹɪli. mɑkɪŋ wɑz fɝɡɑɾən wən ðə dɑɹk ɝaʊn əm wɑz ɹɪmɛmbɝd. hi ɹoʊl ði ʌðɝ weɪ, ən pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɪz aɪz oʊpən, tu. pɛɹɪnz feɪs wɑz lɛs əfɹeɪd ðən mæts, bʌɾ i hæɾ ɪz hænz ɑn ɪz tʃɛst, tæpɪŋ ɪz θʌmz təɡɛðɝ wɝidli.

When he turned one way he found Mat looking at him; looking through him, really. Mocking was forgotten when the dark around them was remembered. He rolled the other way, and Perrin had his eyes open, too. Perrin's face was less afraid than Mat's, but he had his hands on his chest, tapping his thumbs together worriedly.

mɔɪɹeɪn meɪɾ ə sɝkəɾ ə ðɛm, nilɪŋ baɪ itʃ pɝsənz hɛɾ ən bɛndɪŋ daʊn tə spik sɔfli. ɹænd kəd nɑt hɪɹ wʌt ʃi sɛd tə pɛɹɪn, bʌɾ ɪt meɪɾ ɪz θʌmz stɑp. wən ʃi bɛn oʊvɝ ɹænd, hɝ feɪs ɔlmoʊs tʌtʃɪŋ hɪz, ʃi sɛɾ ɪn ə loʊ, kʌmfɝɾɪŋ vɔɪs, "ivən hɪɹ, jəɹ dɛstəni pɹətɛks ju. nɑɾ ivən ðə dɑɹk wʌn kən tʃeɪnʒ ðə pæɾɝn kəmplitli. jə ɑɹ seɪf fɹəm hɪm, soʊ lɔŋ əz aɪm kloʊs. jəɹ dʒɹimz ɑɹ seɪf. fəɹ ə taɪm, jɛt, ðeɪ ɑɹ seɪf."

Moiraine made a circuit of them, kneeling by each person's head and bending down to speak softly. Rand could not hear what she said to Perrin, but it made his thumbs stop. When she bent over Rand, her face almost touching his, she said in a low, comforting voice, "Even here, your destiny protects you. Not even the Dark One can change the Pattern completely. You are safe from him, so long as I am close. Your dreams are safe. For a time, yet, they are safe."

əz ʃi pæs fɹəm ɪm tə mæt, hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf ʃi θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ðət sɪmpəl, ðət ʃi kəd tɛl ɪm i wɑz seɪf ən i wəd bɪliv ɪt. bʌt sʌmhaʊ hi dɪd fil seɪf - seɪfɝ, ət list. θɪŋkɪŋ ðæt, hi dʒɹɪftəɾ ɪndə slip ən dɪd nɑt dʒɹim.

As she passed from him to Mat, he wondered if she thought it was that simple, that she could tell him he was safe and he would believe it. But somehow he did feel safe - safer, at least. Thinking that, he drifted into sleep and did not dream.

læn woʊk ðɛm. ɹænd wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæd slɛpt; hi dɪd nɑt lʊk taɪɝd, nɑɾ ivən əz taɪɝɾ əz ðoʊz u hæd leɪd səm aʊɝz ɑn ðə hɑɹd stoʊn. mɔɪɹeɪn əlaʊɾ ɪnʌf taɪm tə meɪk ti, bʌɾ oʊnli wʌn kʌp əpis. ðeɪ eɪt bɹɛkfəst ɪn ðə sæɾəl, lɔɪəl ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ liɾɪŋ. ɪt wɑz ðə seɪm mil əz ði ʌðɝz, bɹɛɾ ən miɾ ən tʃiz. ɹænd θɔɾ ɪt wəd bi izi tə ɡɛt taɪɝɾ ə bɹɛɾ ən miɾ ən tʃiz.

Lan woke them. Rand wondered if the Warder had slept; he did not look tired, not even as tired as those who had laid some hours on the hard stone. Moiraine allowed enough time to make tea, but only one cup apiece. They ate breakfast in the saddle, Loial and the Warder leading. It was the same meal as the others, bread and meat and cheese. Rand thought it would be easy to get tired of bread and meat and cheese.

nɑt lɔŋ æftɝ ðə læs kɹʌm wɑz lɪkt ɔf ə fɪŋɡɝ, læn sɛd kwaɪətli, "sʌmwʌn ɪz fɑloʊɪŋ ʌs. əɹ sʌmθɪŋ." ðeɪ wɝ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə bɹɪdʒ, boʊθ ɛnz ʌv ɪt hɪɾən.

Not long after the last crumb was licked off a finger, Lan said quietly, "Someone is following us. Or something." They were in the middle of a bridge, both ends of it hidden.

mæt dʒɝkt ən æɹoʊ fɹəm ɪz kwɪvɝ ænd, bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn kəd stɑp hɪm, lust ɪɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk bɪhaɪn ðɛm.

Mat jerked an arrow from his quiver and, before anyone could stop him, loosed it in the dark behind them.

"aɪ nu aɪ ʃʊdn əv dʌn ðɪs," lɔɪəl mʌɾɝd. "nɛvɝ dil wɪð ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪksɛpt ɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ."

"I knew I shouldn't have done this," Loial muttered. "Never deal with an Aes Sedai except in a stedding."

læn pʊʃt ðə baʊ daʊn bɪfɔɹ mæt kəd nɑk ənʌðɝ. "stɑp ðæt, jə vɪlədʒ ɪɾiət. ðɛɹz noʊ weɪ tə tɛl u ɪɾ ɪz."

Lan pushed the bow down before Mat could nock another. "Stop that, you village idiot. There's no way to tell who it is."

"ðæts ði oʊnli pleɪs ðəɹ seɪf," ði oʊɡiɝ wɛn ɑn.

"That's the only place they're safe," the Ogier went on.

"wʌɾ ɛls wəd bi ɪn ə pleɪs laɪk ðɪs bɪsaɪdz sʌmθɪŋ ivəl?" mæt dɪmændəd.

"What else would be in a place like this besides something evil?" Mat demanded.

"ðæts wʌt ði ɛldɝz seɪ, ən aɪ ʃʊɾə lɪsən tə ðɛm."

"That's what the Elders say, and I should have listened to them."

"wi ɑɹ, fəɹ wʌn," ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd dʒɹaɪli.

"We are, for one," the Warder said dryly.

"meɪbi ɪts ənʌðɝ tʃɹævəlɝ," ɛɡwin sɛd hoʊpfəli. "æn oʊɡiɝ, pɝhæps."

"Maybe it's another traveler," Egwene said hopefully. "An Ogier, perhaps."

"oʊɡiɝ əv mɔɹ sɛns ðən tə juz ðə weɪz," lɔɪəl ɡɹaʊld. "ɔl bʌt lɔɪəl, hu hæz noʊ sɛns əɾ ɔl. ɛldɝ heɪmən ɔlweɪz sɛɾ ɪt, ən ɪts tʃɹu."

"Ogier have more sense than to use the Ways," Loial growled. "All but Loial, who has no sense at all. Elder Haman always said it, and it's true."

"wʌt dʒju fil, læn?" mɔɪɹeɪn æskt. "ɪz ɪt sʌmθɪŋ ðət sɝvz ðə dɑɹk wʌn?"

"What do you feel, Lan?" Moiraine asked. "Is it something that serves the Dark One?"

ðə wɔɹɾɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sloʊli. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ," hi sɛɾ əz ɪf ðət sɝpɹaɪz hɪm. "aɪ kænɑt tɛl. pɝhæps ɪts ðə weɪz, ən ðə teɪnt. ɪɾ ɔl filz ɹɔŋ. bʌt huɛvɝ ɪɾ ɪz, əɹ wʌɾ ɛvɝ, hiz nɑt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kætʃ ʌs. hi ɔlmoʊs kɑɾ ʌp ət ðə læst aɪlən ən skæmpɝd bæk əkɹɔs ðə bɹɪdʒ soʊ əz nɑt tə. ɪf aɪ fɔl bɪhaɪnd, aɪ maɪt sɝpɹaɪz ɪm ðoʊ, ən si hu, əɹ wʌt, hi ɪz."

The Warder shook his head slowly. "I don't know," he said as if that surprised him. "I cannot tell. Perhaps it's the Ways, and the taint. It all feels wrong. But whoever it is, or what ever, he's not trying to catch us. He almost caught up at the last Island and scampered back across the bridge so as not to. If I fall behind, I might surprise him though, and see who, or what, he is."

"ɪf jə fɔl bɪhaɪnd, wɔɹɾɝ," lɔɪəl sɛd fɝmli, "jul spɛn ðə ɹɛst ə jəɹ laɪf ɪn ðə weɪz. ivən ɪf jə kən ɹiɾ oʊɡiɝ, aɪ hæv nɛvɝ hɝɾ əɹ ɹɛɾ ʌv ə hjumən u kəd faɪn ɪz pæθ ɔf ðə fɝst aɪlən lækɪŋ ən oʊɡiɝ ɡaɪd. kən jə ɹɛɾ oʊɡiɝ?"

"If you fall behind, Warder," Loial said firmly, "you'll spend the rest of your life in the Ways. Even if you can read Ogier, I have never heard or read of a human who could find his path off the first Island lacking an Ogier guide. Can you read Ogier?"

læn ʃʊk ɪz hɛɾ əɡɛn, ən mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "soʊ lɔŋ əz i dʌz nɑt tʃɹʌbəl ʌs, wɪl nɑt tʃɹʌbəl hɪm. wɪv noʊ taɪm. noʊ taɪm."

Lan shook his head again, and Moiraine said, "So long as he does not trouble us, we will not trouble him. We have no time. No time."

əz ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɔf ðə bɹɪdʒ ɑntu ðə nɛkst aɪlənd, lɔɪəl sɛd, "ɪf aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə læst ɡaɪɾɪŋ kɝɛkli, ðəɹ ɪz ə pæθ fɹəm hɪɹ ðət lidz təwɔɹd tɑɹ vəlɑn. hæf ə deɪz dʒɝni ət moʊst. nɑt kwaɪɾ əz lɔŋ əz ɪɾəl teɪk əs tə ɹitʃ mæfəl dɑɾɝɑnɛl. aɪm ʃʊɹ ðət - "

As they rode off the bridge onto the next Island, Loial said, "If I remember the last Guiding correctly, there is a path from here that leads toward Tar Valon. Half a day's journey at most. Not quite as long as it will take us to reach Mafal Dadaranell. I'm sure that - "

hi kʌɾ ɔf əz ðə laɪɾ ə ðɛɹ læntɝnz ɹitʃt ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ. nɪɹ ðə tɑp ə ðə slæb, dipli tʃɪzəld laɪnz, ʃɑɹp ən æŋɡjəlɝ, meɪd wunz ɪn ðə stoʊn. sʌɾənli lænz əlɝtnəs wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ hɪɾən. hi ɹɪmeɪn izəli ɪɹɛkt ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, bʌt ɹænd hæd ðə sʌɾən ɪmpɹɛʃən ðət ðə wɔɹɾɝ kəd fil ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɝaʊn hɪm, ivən fil ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm bɹiðɪŋ. læn bɪɡæn sɝkəlɪŋ ɪz stæljən ɝaʊn ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ, spaɪɹəlɪŋ aʊtwɝd. hi ɹoʊɾ əz ɪf i wɝ ɹɛɾi tə bi ətækt, əɹ tə ətæk hɪmsɛlf.

He cut off as the light of their lanterns reached the Guiding. Near the top of the slab, deeply chiseled lines, sharp and angular, made wounds in the stone. Suddenly Lan's alertness was no longer hidden. He remained easily erect in his saddle, but Rand had the sudden impression that the Warder could feel everything around him, even feel the rest of them breathing. Lan began circling his stallion around the Guiding, spiraling outward. He rode as if he were ready to be attacked, or to attack himself.

"ðɪs ɪkspleɪnz mʌtʃ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd sɔfli, "æn ɪt meɪks mi əfɹeɪd. soʊ mʌtʃ. aɪ ʃəɾ əv ɡɛst. ðə teɪnt, ðə dəkeɪ. aɪ ʃəɾ əv ɡɛst."

"This explains much," Moiraine said softly, "and it makes me afraid. So much. I should have guessed. The taint, the decay. I should have guessed."

"ɡɛst wʌt?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd dʒʌst əz lɔɪəl æskt, "wʌɾ ɪz ɪt? hu dɪd ðɪs? aɪv nɛvɝ sin əɹ hɝɾ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ laɪk ɪt."

"Guessed what?" Nynaeve demanded just as Loial asked, "What is it? Who did this? I've never seen or heard of anything like it."

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ feɪst əm kɑmli. "tʃɹɑləks." ʃi ɪɡnɔɹd ðɛɹ fɹaɪɾənd ɡæsps. "ɔɹ feɪdz. ðoʊz ɑɹ tʃɹɑlɑk ɹunz. ðə tʃɹɑləks əv dɪskʌvɝd haʊ tə ɛntɝ ðə weɪz. ðət mʌs bi haʊ ðeɪ ɡɑt tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ʌndɪskʌvɝd; θɹu ðə weɪɡeɪɾ ət meɪnɛðɝən. ðəɹ ɪz ət list wʌn weɪɡeɪɾ ɪn ðə blaɪt." ʃi ɡlæns təwɔɹd læn bɪfɔɹ kəntɪnjuɪŋ; ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz fɑɹ ɪnʌf əweɪ ðəɾ oʊnli ðə feɪn laɪɾ ə hɪz læntɝn kəd bi sin. "meɪnɛðɝən wɑz dɪstʃɹɔɪd, bʌɾ ɔlmoʊs nʌθɪŋ kən dɪstʃɹɔɪ ə weɪɡeɪt. ðəɾ ɪz haʊ ðə feɪdz kəd ɡæðɝ ə smɔl ɑɹmi ɝaʊn keɪɛmlɪn wɪθaʊt ɹeɪzɪŋ ən əlɑɹm ɪn ɛvɹi neɪʃən bɪtwin ðə blaɪɾ ən ændɝ." pɔzɪŋ, ʃi tʌtʃt əɹ lɪps θɔtfəli. "bʌt ðeɪ kænɑt noʊ ɔl ðə pæðz jɛt, ɛls ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn pɔɹɪŋ ɪndə keɪɛmlɪn θɹu ðə ɡeɪt wi juzd. jɛs."

The Aes Sedai faced them calmly. "Trollocs." She ignored their frightened gasps. "Or Fades. Those are Trolloc runes. The Trollocs have discovered how to enter the Ways. That must be how they got to the Two Rivers undiscovered; through the Waygate at Manetheren. There is at least one Waygate in the Blight." She glanced toward Lan before continuing; the Warder was far enough away that only the faint light of his lantern could be seen. "Manetheren was destroyed, but almost nothing can destroy a Waygate. That is how the Fades could gather a small army around Caemlyn without raising an alarm in every nation between the Blight and Andor." Pausing, she touched her lips thoughtfully. "But they cannot know all the paths yet, else they would have been pouring into Caemlyn through the gate we used. Yes."

ɹænd ʃɪvɝd. wɔkɪŋ θɹu ðə weɪɡeɪt tə faɪn tʃɹɑləks weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə dɑɹk, hʌnʒɹədz ə ðɛm, pɝhæps θaʊzənz, twɪstəd dʒaɪəns wɪð hæf-ænəməl feɪsəz snɑɹlɪŋ əz ðeɪ lɛp fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ðə blæknəs tə kɪl. əɹ wɝs.

Rand shivered. Walking through the Waygate to find Trollocs waiting in the dark, hundreds of them, perhaps thousands, twisted giants with half-animal faces snarling as they leaped forward in the blackness to kill. Or worse.

"ðeɪ doʊn juz ðə weɪz izəli," læn kɔld. hɪz læntɝn wɑz noʊ mɔɹ ðən twɛnti spænz ɔf, bʌt ðə laɪɾ ʌv ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə dɪm, fʌzi bɔl ðət sim vɛɹi dɪstən tə ðoʊz ɝaʊn ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ. mɔɪɹeɪn lɛd ðə weɪ tə hɪm. ɹænd wɪʃt ɪz stʌmək wɝ ɛmpti wən i sɔ wʌt ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæd faʊnd.

"They don't use the Ways easily," Lan called. His lantern was no more than twenty spans off, but the light of it was only a dim, fuzzy ball that seemed very distant to those around the Guiding. Moiraine led the way to him. Rand wished his stomach were empty when he saw what the Warder had found.

ət ðə fʊɾ ʌv wʌn ə ðə bɹɪdʒəz ðə fɹoʊzən ʃeɪps ə tʃɹɑləks ɹɪɹd, kɑt fleɪlɪŋ əbaʊɾ əm wɪð hʊkt æksiz ən saɪð-laɪk sɔɹdz. ɡɹeɪ ən pɪɾəd laɪk ðə stoʊn, ðə hjudʒ bɑɾiz wɝ hæf sʌŋkən ɪn ðə swoʊlən, bʌbəl sɝfəs. səm ə ðə bʌbəlz hæd bɝst, ɹɪvilɪŋ mɔɹ snaʊɾəd feɪsəz, fɝɛvɝ snɑɹlɪŋ wɪð fɪɹ. ɹænd hɝd sʌmwʌn ɹɛtʃɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm, ən swɑloʊd hɑɹd tə kip fɹəm dʒɔɪnɪŋ huɛvɝ ɪt wɑz. ivən fəɹ tʃɹɑləks ɪt hæd bɪn ə hɔɹəbəl weɪ tə daɪ.

At the foot of one of the bridges the frozen shapes of Trollocs reared, caught flailing about them with hooked axes and scythe-like swords. Gray and pitted like the stone, the huge bodies were half sunken in the swollen, bubbled surface. Some of the bubbles had burst, revealing more snouted faces, forever snarling with fear. Rand heard someone retching behind him, and swallowed hard to keep from joining whoever it was. Even for Trollocs it had been a horrible way to die.

ə fju fit bɪɑn ðə tʃɹɑləks ðə bɹɪdʒ ɛndəd. ðə saɪnpoʊs leɪ ʃæɾɝd ɪndə ə θaʊzənd ʃɑɹdz.

A few feet beyond the Trollocs the bridge ended. The signpost lay shattered into a thousand shards.

lɔɪəl ɡɑt daʊn fɹəm ɪz hɔɹs dʒɪnʒɝli, aɪɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑləks, əz ɪf i θɔt ðeɪ maɪt kʌm bæk tə laɪf. hi ɪɡzæmən ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ə ðə saɪnpoʊs hɝidli, pɪkɪŋ aʊt ðə mɛɾəl skɹɪp ðət hæd bɪn ɪnleɪɾ ɪn ðə stoʊn, ðən skɹæmbəl bæk ɪndə hɪz sæɾəl. "ðɪs wɑz ðə fɝs bɹɪdʒ ə ðə pæθ fɹəm hɪɹ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn," hi sɛd.

Loial got down from his horse gingerly, eyeing the Trollocs, as if he thought they might come back to life. He examined the remains of the signpost hurriedly, picking out the metal script that had been inlaid in the stone, then scrambled back into his saddle. "This was the first bridge of the path from here to Tar Valon," he said.

mæt wɑz skɹʌbɪŋ ðə bæk ə hɪz hæn əkɹɔs ɪz maʊθ, wɪð ɪz hɛd tɝn əweɪ fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑləks. ɛɡwin hɪɾ əɹ feɪs ɪn əɹ hænz. ɹænd muvd ɪz hɔɹs kloʊs tə bɛlə ən tʌtʃt əɹ ʃoʊldɝ. ʃi twɪstəɾ ɝaʊn ən klʌtʃt hɪm, ʃʌɾɝɪŋ. hi wɑntəd tə ʃʌɾɝ, tu; hɝ hoʊldɪŋ ɪm wɑz ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət kɛpt ɪm fɹəm ɪt.

Mat was scrubbing the back of his hand across his mouth, with his head turned away from the Trollocs. Egwene hid her face in her hands. Rand moved his horse close to Bela and touched her shoulder. She twisted around and clutched him, shuddering. He wanted to shudder, too; her holding him was the only thing that kept him from it.

"æz wɛl wəɹ nɑt ɡoʊɪŋ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn jɛt," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd.

"As well we are not going to Tar Valon yet," Moiraine said.

nɪneɪiv ɹaʊndəɾ ɑn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. "haʊ kən jə teɪk ɪt soʊ kɑmli? ðə seɪm kəd hæpən tə ʌs!"

Nynaeve rounded on the Aes Sedai. "How can you take it so calmly? The same could happen to us!"

"pɝhæps," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd sɝinəli, ən nɪneɪiv ɡɹaʊn əɹ tiθ soʊ hɑɹd ɹænd kəd hɪɹ əm ɡɹeɪt. "ɪɾ ɪz mɔɹ laɪkli, ðoʊ," mɔɪɹeɪn wɛn ɑn, ənɹʌfəld, "ðæt ðə mɛn, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, hu meɪd ðə weɪz pɹətɛktəd ðɛm, bɪldɪŋ ɪn tʃɹæps fəɹ kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ɪts sʌmθɪŋ ðeɪ mʌst əv fɪɹd ðɛn, bɪfɔɹ ðə hæfmən ən tʃɹɑləks hæd bɪn dʒɹɪvən ɪndə ðə blaɪt. ɪn ɛni keɪs, wi kænɑt tɛɹi hɪɹ, ən wʌtɛvɝ weɪ wi tʃuz, bæk əɹ əhɛd, ɪz əz laɪkli tə hæv ə tʃɹæp əz ɛni ʌðɝ. lɔɪəl, dʒju noʊ ðə nɛks bɹɪdʒ?"

"Perhaps," Moiraine said serenely, and Nynaeve ground her teeth so hard Rand could hear them grate. "It is more likely, though," Moiraine went on, unruffled, "that the men, the Aes Sedai, who made the Ways protected them, building in traps for creatures of the Dark One. It is something they must have feared then, before the Halfmen and Trollocs had been driven into the Blight. In any case, we cannot tarry here, and Whatever way we choose, back or ahead, is as likely to have a trap as any other. Loial, do you know the next bridge?"

"jɛs. jɛs, ðeɪ dɪd nɑt ɹuən ðət pɑɹɾ ə ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ, θæŋk ðə laɪt." fəɹ ðə fɝs taɪm lɔɪəl simd əz iɡɝ tə ɡoʊ ɑn əz mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd. hi hæɾ ɪz bɪɡ hɔɹs muvɪŋ bɪfɔɹ i fɪnɪʃt spikɪŋ.

"Yes. Yes, they did not ruin that part of the Guiding, thank the Light." For the first time Loial seemed as eager to go on as Moiraine did. He had his big horse moving before he finished speaking.

ɛɡwin klʌŋ tə ɹændz ɑɹm fəɹ tu mɔɹ bɹɪdʒəz. hi ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd ɪt wən ʃi faɪnəli lɛt ɡoʊ wɪð ə mɝmɝɾ əpɑlədʒi ən ə fɔɹs læf, ən nɑt dʒʌs kəz ɪt hæd fɛlt ɡʊd hævɪŋ əɹ hoʊld ɑntu hɪm ðət weɪ. ɪt wɑz iziɝ tə bi bɹeɪv, hi dɪskʌvɝd, wən sʌmwʌn niɾəd jəɹ pɹətɛkʃən.

Egwene clung to Rand's arm for two more bridges. He regretted it when she finally let go with a murmured apology and a forced laugh, and not just because it had felt good having her hold onto him that way. It was easier to be brave, he discovered, when someone needed your protection.

mɔɪɹeɪn maɪt nɑɾ əv bɪlivd ə tʃɹæp kəd bi sɛt fəɹ ðɛm, bʌt fəɹ ɔl ðə heɪst ʃi spoʊk ʌv, ʃi meɪɾ əm tʃɹævəl mɔɹ sloʊli ðən bɪfɔɹ, pɔzɪŋ bɪfɔɹ lɛɾɪŋ əm ɑntu ɛni bɹɪdʒ, əɹ ɔf wʌn ɑntu ən aɪlənd. ʃi wəd stɛp ɑldib fɔɹwɝd, filɪŋ ði ɛɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ wɪð ən aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt hænd, ən nɑɾ ivən lɔɪəl, əɹ læn, wɑz əlaʊd tə ɡoʊ əhɛɾ əntɪl ʃi ɡeɪv pɝmɪʃən.

Moiraine might not have believed a trap could be set for them, but for all the haste she spoke of, she made them travel more slowly than before, pausing before letting them onto any bridge, or off one onto an Island. She would step Aldieb forward, feeling the air in front of her with an outstretched hand, and not even Loial, or Lan, was allowed to go ahead until she gave permission.

ɹænd hæd tə tʃɹʌst əɹ dʒʌdʒmən əbaʊt tʃɹæps, bʌɾ i pɪɹɾ ɪndə ðə dɑɹknəs ɝaʊn əm əz ɪf i kəɾ æktʃəli  si ɛniθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən tɛn fiɾ əweɪ, ən stʃɹeɪn ɪz ɪɹz lɪsnɪŋ. ɪf tʃɹɑləks kəd juz ðə weɪz, ðən wʌtɛvɝ wɑz fɑloʊɪŋ əm kəd bi ənʌðɝ kɹitʃɝ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. əɹ mɔɹ ðən wʌn. læn hæd sɛɾ i kəd nɑt tɛl ɪn ðə weɪz. bʌɾ əz ðeɪ kɹɔs bɹɪdʒ æftɝ bɹɪdʒ, eɪɾ ə mɪddeɪ mil ɹaɪɾɪŋ, ən kɹɔst stɪl mɔɹ bɹɪdʒəz, ɔl i kəd hɪɹ wɝ ðɛɹ oʊn sæɾəlz kɹikɪŋ, ən ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz, ən səmtaɪmz wʌn ə ði ʌðɝz kɑfɪŋ, əɹ mʌɾɝɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf. leɪɾɝ ðəɹ wɑz ə dɪstənt wɪnd, tu, ɔf ɪn ðə blæk sʌmwɛɹ. hi kəd nɑt seɪ ɪn wɪtʃ dɝɛkʃən. ət fɝst i θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən, bʌt wɪð taɪm i bɪkeɪm ʃʊɹ.

Rand had to trust her judgment about traps, but he peered into the darkness around them as if he could actually see anything more than ten feet away, and strained his ears listening. If Trollocs could use the Ways, then Whatever was following them could be another creature of the Dark One. Or more than one. Lan had said he could not tell in the Ways. But as they crossed bridge after bridge, ate a midday meal riding, and crossed still more bridges, all he could hear were their own saddles creaking, and the horses' hooves, and sometimes one of the others coughing, or muttering to himself. Later there was a distant wind, too, off in the black somewhere. He could not say in which direction. At first he thought it was his imagination, but with time he became sure.

ɪɾəl bi ɡʊd tə fil ðə wɪn əɡɛn, ivən ɪf ɪts koʊld.

It'll be good to feel the wind again, even if it's cold.

sʌɾənli hi blɪŋkt. "lɔɪəl, dɪdn jə seɪ ðəɹ ɪzən ɛni wɪn ɪn ðə weɪz?"

Suddenly he blinked. "Loial, didn't you say there isn't any wind in the Ways?"

lɔɪəl pʊld ɪz hɔɹs ʌp dʒʌst ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə nɛkst aɪlən ən kɑkt ɪz hɛd tə lɪsən. sloʊli hɪz feɪs peɪld, ən i lɪkt ɪz lɪps. "mætʃɪn ʃɪn," hi wɪspɝd hɔɹsli. "ðə blæk waɪnd. ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin ən pɹətɛkt ʌs. ɪts ðə blæk wɪnd."

Loial pulled his horse up just short of the next Island and cocked his head to listen. Slowly his face paled, and he licked his lips. "Machin Shin," he whispered hoarsely. "The Black Wind. The Light illumine and protect us. It's the Black Wind."

"haʊ mɛni mɔɹ bɹɪdʒəz?" mɔɪɹeɪn æskt ʃɑɹpli. "lɔɪəl, haʊ mɛni mɔɹ bɹɪdʒəz?"

"How many more bridges?" Moiraine asked sharply. "Loial, how many more bridges?"

"tu. aɪ θɪŋk, tu."

"Two. I think, two."

"kwɪkli, ðɛn," ʃi sɛd, tʃɹɑɾɪŋ ɑldib ɑntu ði aɪlənd. "faɪn ɪt kwɪkli!"

"Quickly, then," she said, trotting Aldieb onto the Island. "Find it quickly!"

lɔɪəl tɔk tə hɪmsɛlf, əɹ tə ɛniwʌn u wɑz lɪsnɪŋ, waɪl i ɹɛd ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ. "ðeɪ keɪm aʊt mæd, skɹimɪŋ əbaʊt mætʃɪn ʃɪn. laɪt hɛlp ʌs! ivən ðoʊz ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd hil, ðeɪ." hi skæn ðə stoʊn heɪstəli, ən ɡæləp təwɔɹd ðə tʃoʊzən bɹɪdʒ wɪð ə ʃaʊɾəd, "ðɪs weɪ!"

Loial talked to himself, or to anyone who was listening, while he read the Guiding. "They came out mad, screaming about Machin Shin. Light help us! Even those Aes Sedai could heal, they." He scanned the stone hastily, and galloped toward the chosen bridge with a shouted, "This way!"

ðɪs taɪm mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd nɑt weɪt tə tʃɛk. ʃi ɝdʒd əm ɑn tə ə ɡæləp, ðə bɹɪdʒ tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ bɪniθ ðə hɔɹsəz, læntɝnz swɪŋɪŋ waɪldli oʊvɝhɛd. lɔɪəl ɹæn ɪz aɪz oʊvɝ ðə nɛkst ɡaɪɾɪŋ ən wild ɪz bɪɡ maʊn ɝaʊn laɪk ə ɹeɪsɝ ɔlmoʊs bɪfɔɹ ɪt hæd stɑpt. ðə saʊn ə ðə wɪn bɪkeɪm laʊɾɝ. ɹænd kəd hɪɹ ɪɾ ivən oʊvɝ ðə paʊndɪŋ ə hʊvz ɑn stoʊn. bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ən ɡʌstɪŋ kloʊsɝ.

This time Moiraine did not wait to check. She urged them on to a gallop, the bridge trembling beneath the horses, lanterns swinging wildly overhead. Loial ran his eyes over the next Guiding and wheeled his big mount around like a racer almost before it had stopped. The sound of the wind became louder. Rand could hear it even over the pounding of hooves on stone. Behind them, and gusting closer.

ðeɪ dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ wɪð ðə læst ɡaɪɾɪŋ. əz sun əz ðə laɪɾ ə ðə læntɝnz kɑt ðə waɪt laɪn ɹʌnɪŋ fɹəm ɪt, ðeɪ swʌŋ ɪn ðət dɝɛkʃən, stɪl ɡæləpɪŋ. ði aɪlən vænɪʃt bɪhaɪnd, ən ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə pɪɾəd, ɡɹeɪ stoʊn ʌndɝfʊɾ ən ðə waɪt laɪn. ɹænd wɑz bɹiðɪŋ soʊ hɑɹɾ i wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ʃʊɹ ɪf i kəd hɪɹ ðə wɪnd.

They did not bother with the last Guiding. As soon as the light of the lanterns caught the white line running from it, they swung in that direction, still galloping. The Island vanished behind, and there was only the pitted, gray stone underfoot and the white line. Rand was breathing so hard he was no longer sure if he could hear the wind.

aʊɾ ə ðə dɑɹknəs ðə ɡeɪts əpɪɹd, vaɪn-kɑɹvd ən stændɪŋ əloʊn ɪn ðə blæk laɪk ə taɪni pis ʌv wɔl ɪn ðə naɪt. mɔɪɹeɪn lin aʊɾ ə hɝ sæɾəl, ɹitʃɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə kɑɹvɪŋz, ən sʌɾənli pʊl bæk. "ði ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə lif ɪz nɑt hɪɹ!" ʃi sɛd. "ðə ki ɪz ɡɔn!"

Out of the darkness the gates appeared, vine-carved and standing alone in the black like a tiny piece of wall in the night. Moiraine leaned out of her saddle, reaching toward the carvings, and suddenly pulled back. "The Avendesora leaf is not here!" she said. "The key is gone!"

"laɪt!" mæt ʃaʊɾəd. "blʌɾi laɪt!" lɔɪəl θɹu bæk ɪz hɛɾ ən ɡeɪv ə mɔɹnfəl kɹaɪ, laɪk ə haʊl ə daɪɪŋ.

"Light!" Mat shouted. "Bloody light!" Loial threw back his head and gave a mournful cry, like a howl of dying.

ɛɡwin tʌtʃt ɹændz ɑɹm. hɝ lɪps tʃɹɛmbəld, bʌt ʃi oʊnli lʊkt ət hɪm. hi pʊɾ ɪz hæn ɑn tɑp ə hɝz, hoʊpɪŋ i dɪd nɑt lʊk mɔɹ fɹaɪɾənd ðən ʃi dɪd. hi fɛlt ɪt. bæk təwɔɹd ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ, ðə wɪn haʊld. hi ɔlmoʊs θɔɾ i kəd hɪɹ vɔɪsəz ɪn ɪt, vɔɪsəz skɹimɪŋ vɪlnəs ðæt, ivən hæf ʌndɝstʊd, bɹɔt baɪl ʌp ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt.

Egwene touched Rand's arm. Her lips trembled, but she only looked at him. He put his hand on top of hers, hoping he did not look more frightened than she did. He felt it. Back toward the Guiding, the wind howled. He almost thought he could hear voices in it, voices screaming vileness that, even half understood, brought bile up in his throat.

mɔɪɹeɪn ɹeɪzd əɹ stæf ən fleɪm læns fɹəm ði ɛn ʌv ɪt. ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə pjʊɹ, waɪt fleɪm ðət ɹænd ɹɪmɛmbɝd fɹəm ɛmənz fild, ən ðə bæɾəl bɪfɔɹ ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. sɪkli jɛloʊ stʃɹik θɹu ðə faɪɝ, ən sloʊ-dʒɹɪftɪŋ flɛks ə blæk, laɪk sʊt. ə θɪn, ækɹɪd smoʊk dʒɹɪftəd fɹəm ðə fleɪm, sɛɾɪŋ lɔɪəl kɑfɪŋ ən ðə hɔɹsəz dænsɪŋ nɝvəsli, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn θɹʌst ɪɾ ət ðə ɡeɪts. ðə smoʊk ɹæspt ɹændz θɹoʊɾ ən bɝn ɪz noʊz.

Moiraine raised her staff and flame lanced from the end of it. It was not the pure, white flame that Rand remembered from Emond's Field, and the battle before Shadar Logoth. Sickly yellow streaked through the fire, and slow-drifting flecks of black, like soot. A thin, acrid smoke drifted from the flame, setting Loial coughing and the horses dancing nervously, but Moiraine thrust it at the gates. The smoke rasped Rand's throat and burned his nose.

stoʊn mɛltəd laɪk bʌɾɝ, lif ən vaɪn wɪðɝɪŋ ɪn ðə fleɪm ən vænɪʃɪŋ. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ muv ðə faɪɝ əz fæst əz ʃi kʊd, bʌt kʌɾɪŋ ən oʊpənɪŋ bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn tə ɡɛt θɹu wɑz noʊ kwɪk tæsk. tə ɹænd, ɪt simd əz ɪf ðə laɪn ə mɛltəd stoʊn kɹɛpt əlɔŋ ɪts ɑɹk əɾ ə sneɪlz peɪs. hɪz kloʊk stɝd, əz ɪf kɑt baɪ ði ɛdʒ ʌv ə bɹiz, ən ɪz hɑɹt fɹoʊz.

Stone melted like butter, leaf and vine withering in the flame and vanishing. The Aes Sedai moved the fire as fast as she could, but cutting an opening big enough for everyone to get through was no quick task. To Rand, it seemed as if the line of melted stone crept along its arc at a snail's pace. His cloak stirred, as if caught by the edge of a breeze, and his heart froze.

"aɪ kən fil ɪt," mæt sɛd, hɪz vɔɪs kweɪvɝɪŋ. "laɪt, aɪ kən blʌɾi fil ɪt!"

"I can feel it," Mat said, his voice quavering. "Light, I can bloody feel it!"

ðə fleɪm wɪŋkt aʊt, ən mɔɪɹeɪn loʊɝɾ əɹ stæf. "dʌn," ʃi sɛd. "hæf dʌn."

The flame winked out, and Moiraine lowered her staff. "Done," she said. "Half done."

ə θɪn laɪn ɹæn əkɹɔs ðə stoʊn kɑɹvɪŋ. ɹænd θɔɾ i kəd si laɪt - dɪm, bʌt stɪl laɪt - θɹu ðə kɹæk. bʌt dɪspaɪt ðə kʌɾɪŋ, ðə tu bɪɡ, kɝvd wɛdʒəz ə stoʊn stɪl stʊd ðɛɹ, hæf ən ɑɹk aʊɾ ʌv itʃ dɔɹ. ði oʊpənɪŋ wəd bi bɪɡ ɪnʌf fəɹ ɛvɹiwʌn tə ɹaɪd θɹu, ðoʊ lɔɪəl maɪɾ əv tə laɪ flæɾ ɑn ɪz hɔɹsəz bæk. wʌns ðə tu wɛdʒəz ə stoʊn wɝ ɡɔn, ɪt wəd bi bɪɡ ɪnʌf. hi wʌndɝd haʊ mʌtʃ itʃ weɪd. ə θaʊzən paʊnz? mɔɹ? meɪbi ɪf wi ɔl ɡɛt daʊn ən pʊʃ. meɪbi wi kən pʊʃ wʌn ə ðɛm oʊvɝ bɪfɔɹ ðə wɪnd ɡɛts hɪɹ. ə ɡʌs tʌɡd əɾ ɪz kloʊk. hi tʃɹaɪd nɑt tə lɪsən tə wʌt ðə vɔɪsəz kɹaɪd.

A thin line ran across the stone carving. Rand thought he could see light - dim, but still light - through the crack. But despite the cutting, the two big, curved wedges of stone still stood there, half an arc out of each door. The opening would be big enough for everyone to ride through, though Loial might have to lie flat on his horse's back. Once the two wedges of stone were gone, it would be big enough. He wondered how much each weighed. A thousand pounds? More? Maybe if we all get down and push. Maybe we can push one of them over before the wind gets here. A gust tugged at his cloak. He tried not to listen to what the voices cried.

əz mɔɪɹeɪn stɛp bæk, mændɑɹb lɛp fɔɹwɝd, stʃɹeɪt təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪts, læn kɹaʊtʃt ɪn ðə sæɾəl. ət ðə læst ɪnstən ðə wɔɹhɔɹs twɪstəd tə kætʃ ðə stoʊn wɪð ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, dʒʌst əz i hæd bɪn tɔt tə kætʃ ʌðɝ hɔɹsəz ɪn bæɾəl. wɪð ə kɹæʃ ðə stoʊn tɑpəld aʊtwɝd, ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ ən ɪz hɔɹs wɝ kæɹid baɪ ðɛɹ moʊmɛntəm θɹu ðə smoʊki ʃɪmɝ ʌv ə weɪɡeɪt. ðə laɪt ðət keɪm θɹu wɑz mɪd-mɔɹnɪŋ laɪt, peɪl ən θɪn, bʌɾ ɪt sim tə ɹænd əz ɪf ðə nundeɪ sʌmɝ sʌn bleɪzd ɪn ɪz feɪs.

As Moiraine stepped back, Mandarb leaped forward, straight toward the gates, Lan crouched in the saddle. At the last instant the warhorse twisted to catch the stone with his shoulder, just as he had been taught to catch other horses in battle. With a crash the stone toppled outward, and the Warder and his horse were carried by their momentum through the smoky shimmer of a Waygate. The light that came through was mid-morning light, pale and thin, but it seemed to Rand as if the noonday summer sun blazed in his face.

ɑn ðə fɑɹ saɪɾ ə ðə ɡeɪt læn ən mændɑɹb sloʊd tə ə kɹɔl, stʌmbəlɪŋ ɪn sloʊ moʊʃən əz ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɹeɪn bæk ɝaʊn təwɔɹd ðə ɡeɪt. ɹænd dɪd nɑt weɪt. pʊʃɪŋ bɛləz hɛd təwɔɹd ði oʊpənɪŋ, hi slæp ðə ʃæɡi mɛɹ hɑɹɾ ɑn ðə kɹup. ɛɡwin hæd dʒʌst ɪnʌf taɪm tə θɹoʊ ə stɑɹɾəld lʊk oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ əɾ ɪm bɪfɔɹ bɛlə kæɹiɾ əɹ aʊɾ ə ðə weɪz.

On the far side of the gate Lan and Mandarb slowed to a crawl, stumbling in slow motion as the Warder reined back around toward the gate. Rand did not wait. Pushing Bela's head toward the opening, he slapped the shaggy mare hard on the croup. Egwene had just enough time to throw a startled look over her shoulder at him before Bela carried her out of the Ways.

"ɔl ə ju, aʊt!" mɔɪɹeɪn dɝɛktəd. "kwɪkli! ɡoʊ!"

"All of you, out!" Moiraine directed. "Quickly! Go!"

əz ʃi spoʊk, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ θɹʌst əɹ stæf aʊɾ əɾ ɑɹmz lɛŋθ, pɔɪntəd bæk təwɔɹd ðə ɡaɪɾɪŋ. sʌmθɪŋ lɛp fɹəm ði ɛn ə ðə stæf, laɪk lɪkwəd laɪt ɹɛndɝd tə ə sɝəp ə faɪɝ, ə bleɪzɪŋ spɪɹ ʌv waɪɾ ən ɹɛɾ ən jɛloʊ, stʃɹikɪŋ ɪndə ðə blæk, ɪksploʊɾɪŋ, kɔɹʌskeɪɾɪŋ laɪk ʃæɾɝd daɪmənz. ðə wɪnd ʃɹikt ɪn æɡəni; ɪt skɹimd ɪn ɹeɪdʒ. ðə θaʊzən mɝmɝz ðət hɪɾ ɪn ðə wɪn ɹɔɹd laɪk θʌndɝ, ɹɔɹz ə mædnəs, hæf-hɝd vɔɪsəz kækəlɪŋ ən haʊlɪŋ pɹɑməsəz ðət twɪstəd ɹændz stʌmək əz mʌtʃ baɪ ðə plɛʒɝ ɪn əm əz baɪ wʌɾ i ɔlmoʊst ʌndɝstʊɾ əm tə seɪ.

As she spoke, the Aes Sedai thrust her staff out at arm's length, pointed back toward the Guiding. Something leaped from the end of the staff, like liquid light rendered to a syrup of fire, a blazing spear of white and red and yellow, streaking into the black, exploding, coruscating like shattered diamonds. The wind shrieked in agony; it screamed in rage. The thousand murmurs that hid in the wind roared like thunder, roars of madness, half-heard voices cackling and howling promises that twisted Rand's stomach as much by the pleasure in them as by what he almost understood them to say.

hi buɾɪd ɹɛd fɔɹwɝd, kɹaʊɾɪŋ ɪndə ði oʊpənɪŋ, skwizɪŋ æftɝ ði ʌðɝz, ɔl fɔɹsɪŋ θɹu ðə smoʊki ɡlɪsnɪŋ ət wʌns. ði aɪsi tʃɪl ɹæn θɹu hɪm əɡɛn, ðə pəkjuljɝ sɛnseɪʃən ə biɪŋ sloʊli loʊɝd feɪsdaʊn ɪndə ə wɪntɝ pɑnd, ðə koʊld wɔɾɝ kɹɔlɪŋ əkɹɔs ɪz skɪn baɪ ɪnfɪnɪtɛsɪməl ɪŋkɹəməns. dʒʌst əz bɪfɔɹ ɪt sim tə ɡoʊ ɑn fɝɛvɝ, waɪl ɪz maɪn ɹeɪst, wʌndɝɪŋ ɪf ðə wɪn kəd kætʃ əm waɪl ðeɪ wɝ hɛld laɪk ðæt.

He booted Red forward, crowding into the opening, squeezing after the others, all forcing through the smoky glistening at once. The icy chill ran through him again, the peculiar sensation of being slowly lowered facedown into a winter pond, the cold water crawling across his skin by infinitesimal increments. Just as before it seemed to go on forever, while his mind raced, wondering if the wind could catch them while they were held like that.

əz sʌɾənli əz ə pɹɪk bʌbəl ðə tʃɪl vænɪʃt, ən i wɑz aʊtsaɪd. hɪz hɔɹs, fəɹ wʌn əbɹʌpt ɪnstən muvɪŋ twaɪs əz fæst əz i hæd bɪn, stʌmbəld ən ɔlmoʊs pɪtʃt ɪm oʊvɝ ɪz hɛd. hi θɹu boʊθ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn ðə beɪz nɛk ən hʌŋ ɑn fəɹ dɪɹ laɪf. waɪl i ɡɑt bæk ɪndə ðə sæɾəl, ɹɛd ʃʊk hɪmsɛlf, ðən tʃɹɑɾəd oʊvɝ tə dʒɔɪn ði ʌðɝz əz kɑmli əz ɪf nʌθɪŋ əɾ ɔl ɑd hæd hæpənd. ɪt wɑz koʊld, nɑt ðə tʃɪl ə ðə weɪɡeɪt, bʌt wɛlkəm, nætʃɹəl wɪntɝ-koʊl ðət sloʊli, stɛɾəli bɝoʊɾ ɪndə flɛʃ.

As suddenly as a pricked bubble the chill vanished, and he was outside. His horse, for one abrupt instant moving twice as fast as he had been, stumbled and almost pitched him over his head. He threw both arms around the bay's neck and hung on for dear life. While he got back into the saddle, Red shook himself, then trotted over to join the others as calmly as if nothing at all odd had happened. It was cold, not the chill of the Waygate, but welcome, natural winter-cold that slowly, steadily burrowed into flesh.

hi pʊld ɪz kloʊk ɝaʊn hɪm, hɪz aɪz ɑn ðə dʌl ɡlɪmɝ ə ðə weɪɡeɪt. bɪsaɪɾ ɪm læn lin fɔɹwɝɾ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, wʌn hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd; mæn ən hɔɹs wɝ tɛnst, əz ɪf ɑn ðə pɔɪn ə tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ bæk θɹu ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ.

He pulled his cloak around him, his eyes on the dull glimmer of the Waygate. Beside him Lan leaned forward in his saddle, one hand on his sword; man and horse were tensed, as if on the point of charging back through if Moiraine did not appear.

ðə weɪɡeɪt stʊɾ ɪn ə dʒʌmbəl ə stoʊnz ət ðə beɪs ʌv ə hɪl, hɪɾən baɪ bʊʃəz ɪksɛpt wɛɹ ðə fɔlɪŋ pisəz hæd bɹoʊkən daʊn ðə bɛɹ, bɹaʊn bɹæntʃəz. əlɔŋsaɪd ðə kɑɹvɪŋz ɑn ðə ɹɪmeɪnz ə ðə ɡeɪts, ðə bɹʌʃ lʊk mɔɹ laɪfləs ðən ðə stoʊn.

The Waygate stood in a jumble of stones at the base of a hill, hidden by bushes except where the falling pieces had broken down the bare, brown branches. Alongside the carvings on the remains of the gates, the brush looked more lifeless than the stone.

sloʊli ðə mɝki sɝfəs bʌlʒd laɪk səm stʃɹeɪnʒ, lɔŋ bʌbəl ɹaɪzɪŋ tə ðə sɝfəs ʌv ə pɑnd. mɔɪɹeɪnz bæk bɹoʊk θɹu ðə bʌbəl. ɪntʃmil, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən əɹ dɪm ɹəflɛkʃən bækt aʊɾ ʌv itʃ ʌðɝ. ʃi stɪl hɛld əɹ stæf aʊɾ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɝ, ən ʃi kɛpt ɪt ðəɹ əz ʃi dʒɹu ɑldib aʊɾ ə ðə weɪɡeɪɾ æftɝ hɝ, ðə waɪt mɛɹ dænsɪŋ wɪð fɪɹ, aɪz ɹoʊlɪŋ. stɪl wɑtʃɪŋ ðə weɪɡeɪt, mɔɪɹeɪn bækt əweɪ.

Slowly the murky surface bulged like some strange, long bubble rising to the surface of a pond. Moiraine's back broke through the bubble. Inchmeal, the Aes Sedai and her dim reflection backed out of each other. She still held her staff out in front of her, and she kept it there as she drew Aldieb out of the Waygate after her, the white mare dancing with fear, eyes rolling. Still watching the Waygate, Moiraine backed away.

ðə weɪɡeɪt dɑɹkənd. ðə heɪzi ʃɪmɝ bɪkeɪm mɝkiɝ, sɪŋkɪŋ θɹu ɡɹeɪ tə tʃɑɹkoʊl, ðən tə blæk əz dip əz ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə weɪz. əz ɪf fɹəm ə ɡɹeɪt dɪstəns ðə wɪn haʊld ət ðɛm, hɪɾən vɔɪsəz fɪld wɪð ən ʊnkwɛnʃəbəl θɝs fəɹ lɪvɪŋ θɪŋz, fɪld wɪð ə hʌŋɡɝ fəɹ peɪn, fɪld wɪð fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən.

The Waygate darkened. The hazy shimmer became murkier, sinking through gray to charcoal, then to black as deep as the heart of the Ways. As if from a great distance the wind howled at them, hidden voices filled with an unquenchable thirst for living things, filled with a hunger for pain, filled with frustration.

ðə vɔɪsəz sim tə wɪspɝ ɪn ɹændz ɪɹz, ɹaɪɾ ət ðə bɹɪŋk ʌv ʌndɝstændɪŋ, ən wɪðɪn ɪt. flɛʃ soʊ faɪn, soʊ faɪn tə tɛɹ, tə ɡæʃ ðə skɪn; skɪn tə stʃɹɪp, tə pleɪt, soʊ naɪs tə pleɪt ðə stʃɹɪps, soʊ naɪs, soʊ ɹɛd ðə dʒɹɑps ðət fɔl; blʌd soʊ ɹɛd, soʊ ɹɛd, soʊ swit; swit skɹimz, pɹɪɾi skɹimz, sɪŋɪŋ skɹimz, skɹim jəɹ sɔŋ, sɪŋ jəɹ skɹimz.

The voices seemed to whisper in Rand's ears, right at the brink of understanding, and within it. Flesh so fine, so fine to tear, to gash the skin; skin to strip, to plait, so nice to plait the strips, so nice, so red the drops that fall; blood so red, so red, so sweet; sweet screams, pretty screams, singing screams, scream your song, sing your screams.

ðə wɪspɝz dʒɹɪftəd, ðə blæknəs lɛsənd, feɪɾəd, ən ðə weɪɡeɪt wɑz əɡɛn ə mɝki ʃɪmɝ sin θɹu ən ɑɹtʃ ə kɑɹv stoʊn.

The whispers drifted, the blackness lessened, faded, and the Waygate was again a murky shimmer seen through an arch of carved stone.

ɹænd lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ, ʃʌɾɝɪŋ bɹɛθ. hi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn; hi hɝɾ ʌðɝ ɹɪlivd ɪkshəleɪʃənz. ɛɡwin hæd bɛlə əlɔŋsaɪd nɪneɪivz hɔɹs, ən ðə tu wɪmən hæd ðɛɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn itʃ ʌðɝ, ðɛɹ hɛdz ɑn itʃ ʌðɝz ʃoʊldɝz. ivən læn simd ɹɪlivd, ðoʊ ðə hɑɹd pleɪnz ə hɪz feɪs ʃoʊd nʌθɪŋ; ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ɪn ðə weɪ hi sæt mændɑɹb, ə lusənɪŋ ə ðə ʃoʊldɝz əz i lʊkt ət mɔɪɹeɪn, ə tɪlt ə ðə hɛd.

Rand let out a long, shuddering breath. He was not the only one; he heard other relieved exhalations. Egwene had Bela alongside Nynaeve's horse, and the two women had their arms around each other, their heads on each other's shoulders. Even Lan seemed relieved, though the hard planes of his face showed nothing; it was more in the way he sat Mandarb, a loosening of the shoulders as he looked at Moiraine, a tilt of the head.

"ɪt kəd nɑt pæs," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "aɪ θɔɾ ɪt kəd nɑt; aɪ hoʊpt ɪt kəd nɑt. fɔ!" ʃi tɔst əɹ stæf ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ən skɹʌbd əɹ hæn ɑn əɹ kloʊk. tʃɑɹ, θɪk ən blæk, mɑɹk ðə stæf fəɹ oʊvɝ hæf ɪts lɛŋθ. "ðə teɪn kɝʌps ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɪn ðət pleɪs."

"It could not pass," Moiraine said. "I thought it could not; I hoped it could not. Faugh!" She tossed her staff on the ground and scrubbed her hand on her cloak. Char, thick and black, marked the staff for over half its length. "The taint corrupts everything in that place."

"wʌt wɑz ðæt?" nɪneɪiv dɪmændəd. "wʌt wɑz ɪt?"

"What was that?" Nynaeve demanded. "What was it?"

lɔɪəl əpɪɹd kənfjuzd. "waɪ, mætʃɪn ʃɪn, ʌv kɔɹs. ðə blæk wɪn ðət stilz soʊlz."

Loial appeared confused. "Why, Machin Shin, of course. The Black Wind that steals souls."

"bʌt wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" nɪneɪiv pɝsɪstəd. "ivən wɪð ə tʃɹɑlɑk, jə kən lʊk əɾ ɪt, tʌtʃ ɪɾ ɪf juv ə stʃɹɔŋ stʌmək. bʌt ðæt." ʃi ɡeɪv ə kənvʌlsɪv ʃɪvɝ.

"But what is it?" Nynaeve persisted. "Even with a Trolloc, you can look at it, touch it if you have a strong stomach. But that." She gave a convulsive shiver.

"sʌmθɪŋ lɛft fɹəm ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, pɝhæps," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "ɔɹ ivən fɹəm ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ, ðə wɔɹ ə paʊɝ. sʌmθɪŋ haɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðə weɪz soʊ lɔŋ ɪt kən noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɡɛɾ aʊt. noʊ wʌn, nɑɾ ivən əmʌŋ ði oʊɡiɝ, noʊz haʊ fɑɹ ðə weɪz ɹʌn, əɹ haʊ dip. ɪt kəɾ ivən bi sʌmθɪŋ ə ðə weɪz ðɛmsɛlvz. əz lɔɪəl sɛd, ðə weɪz ɑɹ lɪvɪŋ θɪŋz, ən ɔl lɪvɪŋ θɪŋz əv pɛɹəsaɪts. pɝhæps ivən ə kɹitʃɝ ə ðə kɝʌpʃən ɪtsɛlf, sʌmθɪŋ bɔɹn ə ðə dəkeɪ. sʌmθɪŋ ðət heɪts laɪf ən laɪt."

"Something left from the Time of Madness, perhaps," Moiraine replied. "Or even from the War of the Shadow, the War of Power. Something hiding in the Ways so long it can no longer get out. No one, not even among the Ogier, knows how far the Ways run, or how deep. It could even be something of the Ways themselves. As Loial said, the Ways are living things, and all living things have parasites. Perhaps even a creature of the corruption itself, something born of the decay. Something that hates life and light."

"stɑp!" ɛɡwin kɹaɪd. "aɪ doʊnt wɑnə hɪɹ ɛni mɔɹ. aɪ kəd hɪɹ ɪt, seɪɪŋ." ʃi kʌɾ ɔf, ʃɪvɝɪŋ.

"Stop!" Egwene cried. "I don't want to hear any more. I could hear it, saying." She cut off, shivering.

"ðɛɹ ɪz wɝs tə bi feɪs jɛt," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd sɔfli. ɹænd dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi mɛn ɪt tə bi hɝd.

"There is worse to be faced yet," Moiraine said softly. Rand did not think she meant it to be heard.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ klaɪmd ɪndə hɝ sæɾəl wɛɹəli ən sɛɾəld ðəɹ wɪð ə ɡɹeɪtfəl saɪ. "ðɪs ɪz deɪnʒɝəs," ʃi sɛd, lʊkɪŋ ət ðə bɹoʊkən ɡeɪts. hɝ tʃɑɹd stæf ɹəsivd oʊnli ə ɡlæns. "ðə θɪŋ kænɑt ɡɛɾ aʊt, bʌɾ ɛniwʌn kəd wɑndɝ ɪn. eɪɡəlmɝ mʌst sɛn mɛn tə wɔl ɪɾ ʌp, wʌns wi ɹitʃ fæl dæɹə." ʃi pɔɪntəd tə ðə nɔɹθ, tə taʊɝz ɪn ðə mɪsti dɪstəns əbʌv ðə bæɹən tʃɹitɑps.

The Aes Sedai climbed into her saddle wearily and settled there with a grateful sigh. "This is dangerous," she said, looking at the broken gates. Her charred staff received only a glance. "The thing cannot get out, but anyone could wander in. Agelmar must send men to wall it up, once we reach Fal Dara." She pointed to the north, to towers in the misty distance above the barren treetops.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾisɪks


CHAPTER 46

fæl dæɹə


Fal Dara

ðə kʌntʃɹi ɝaʊn ðə weɪɡeɪt wɑz ɹoʊlɪŋ, fɔɹəstəd hɪlz, bʌɾ əsaɪd fɹəm ðə ɡeɪts ðɛmsɛlvz ðəɹ wɑz noʊ saɪn ʌv ɛni oʊɡiɝ ɡɹoʊv. moʊst ə ðə tʃɹiz wɝ ɡɹeɪ skɛləɾənz klɔɪŋ ət ðə skaɪ. fjuɝ ɛvɝɡɹinz ðən ɹænd wɑz juz tə dɑɾəd ðə fɔɹəst, ən ə ðɛm, dɛd, bɹaʊn niɾəlz ən livz kʌvɝd mɛni. lɔɪəl meɪd noʊ kɑmɛn bɪɑn ə sæd ʃeɪkɪŋ ə hɪz hɛd.

The country around the Waygate was rolling, forested hills, but aside from the gates themselves there was no sign of any Ogier grove. Most of the trees were gray skeletons clawing at the sky. Fewer evergreens than Rand was used to dotted the forest, and of them, dead, brown needles and leaves covered many. Loial made no comment beyond a sad shaking of his head.

"æz dɛɾ əz ðə blæstəd lænz," nɪneɪiv sɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ. ɛɡwin pʊld əɹ kloʊk ɝaʊn əɹ ən ʃɪvɝd.

"As dead as the Blasted Lands," Nynaeve said, frowning. Egwene pulled her cloak around her and shivered.

"æt list wɝ aʊt," pɛɹɪn sɛd, ən mæt æɾəd, "aʊt wɛɹ?"

"At least we're out," Perrin said, and Mat added, "Out where?"

"ʃaɪnɝ," læn toʊl ðɛm. "wɝ ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz." ɪn ɪz hɑɹd vɔɪs wɑz ə noʊt ðət sɛd hoʊm, ɔlmoʊst.

"Shienar," Lan told them. "We're in the Borderlands." In his hard voice was a note that said home, almost.

ɹænd ɡæðɝɾ ɪz kloʊk əɡɛns ðə koʊld. ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ðən ðə blaɪt wɑz kloʊs baɪ. ðə blaɪt. ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld. ən wʌt ðeɪ hæd kʌm tə du.

Rand gathered his cloak against the cold. The Borderlands. Then the Blight was close by. The Blight. The Eye of the World. And what they had come to do.

"wi ɑɹ kloʊs tə fæl dæɹə," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "oʊnli ə fju maɪlz." əkɹɔs ðə tʃɹitɑps, taʊɝz ɹoʊz tə ðə nɔɹθ ən ist ə ðɛm, dɑɹk əɡɛns ðə mɔɹnɪŋ skaɪ. bɪtwin ðə hɪlz ən ðə wʊdz, ðə taʊɝz ɔfən vænɪʃt əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd, oʊnli tə ɹiəpɪɹ əɡɛn wən ðeɪ tɑpt ə pɑɹtɪkjəlɝli tɔl ɹaɪz.

"We are close to Fal Dara," Moiraine said. "Only a few miles." Across the treetops, towers rose to the north and east of them, dark against the morning sky. Between the hills and the woods, the towers often vanished as they rode, only to reappear again when they topped a particularly tall rise.

ɹænd noʊɾəst tʃɹiz splɪɾ oʊpən əz ɪf stʃɹʌk baɪ laɪtnɪŋ.

Rand noticed trees split open as if struck by lightning.

"ðə koʊld," læn ænsɝd wən i æskt. "səmtaɪmz ðə wɪntɝ ɪz soʊ koʊl hɪɹ ðə sæp fɹizɪz, ən tʃɹiz bɝst. ðəɹ ɑɹ naɪts wən jə kən hɪɹ əm kɹækɪŋ laɪk faɪɹwɝks, ən ði ɛɹ ɪz soʊ ʃɑɹp jə θɪŋk ðət maɪt ʃæɾɝ, tu. ðəɹ ɑɹ mɔɹ ðən juʒəwəl, ðɪs wɪntɝ pæst."

"The cold," Lan answered when he asked. "Sometimes the winter is so cold here the sap freezes, and trees burst. There are nights when you can hear them cracking like fireworks, and the air is so sharp you think that might shatter, too. There are more than usual, this winter past."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. tʃɹiz bɝstɪŋ? ən ðət wɑz dʊɹɪŋ ən ɔɹɾənɛɹi wɪntɝ. wʌt mʌs ðɪs wɪntɝ əv bɪn laɪk? ʃʊɹli laɪk nʌθɪŋ i kəɾ ɪmædʒən.

Rand shook his head. Trees bursting? And that was during an ordinary winter. What must this winter have been like? Surely like nothing he could imagine.

"hu sɛz wɪntɝz pæst?" mæt sɛd, hɪz tiθ tʃæɾɝɪŋ.

"Who says winter's past?" Mat said, his teeth chattering.

"waɪ ðɪs, ə faɪn spɹɪŋ, ʃifɝɾɝ," læn sɛd. "ə faɪn spɹɪŋ tə bi əlaɪv. bʌɾ ɪf jə wɑnt wɔɹm, wɛl, ɪɾəl bi wɔɹm ɪn ðə blaɪt."

"Why this, a fine spring, sheepherder," Lan said. "A fine spring to be alive. But if you want warm, well, it will be warm in the Blight."

sɔfli mæt mʌɾɝd, "blʌɾ ən æʃəz. blʌɾ ən blʌɾi æʃəz!" ɹænd bɛɹli hɝd hɪm, bʌɾ ɪt saʊndəd hɑɹtfɛlt.

Softly Mat muttered, "Blood and ashes. Blood and bloody ashes!" Rand barely heard him, but it sounded heartfelt.

ðeɪ bɪɡæn tə pæs fɑɹmz, bʌt ðoʊ ɪt wɑz ði aʊɝ fəɹ mɪddeɪ milz tə bi kʊkɪŋ, noʊ smoʊk ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə haɪ stoʊn tʃɪmniz. ðə filz wɝ ɛmpti ʌv mɛn ən laɪvstɑk boʊθ, ðoʊ səmtaɪmz ə plaʊ əɹ ə wæɡən stʊɾ əbændən əz ɪf ði oʊnɝ mɛn tə bi bæk ɛni mɪnət.

They began to pass farms, but though it was the hour for midday meals to be cooking, no smoke rose from the high stone chimneys. The fields were empty of men and livestock both, though sometimes a plow or a wagon stood abandoned as if the owner meant to be back any minute.

ət wʌn fɑɹm kloʊs baɪ ðə ɹoʊɾ ə loʊn tʃɪkən skɹætʃt ɪn ðə jɑɹd. wʌn bɑɹn dɔɹ swʌŋ fɹili wɪð ðə wɪnd; ði ʌðɝ hæd bɹoʊkən ɔf ðə bɑɾəm hɪnʒ ən hʌŋ əɾ ən æŋɡəl. ðə tɔl haʊs, ɑd tə ɹændz tu ɹɪvɝz aɪz, wɪð ɪts ʃɑɹp-pikt ɹuf ə bɪɡ wʊɾən ʃɪŋɡəlz ɹʌnɪŋ ɔlmoʊs tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd, wɑz stɪl ən saɪlənt. noʊ dɔɡ keɪm aʊt tə bɑɹk ət ðɛm. ə saɪð leɪ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə bɑɹnjɑɹd; bʌkəts wɝ oʊvɝtɝn ɪn ə hip bɪsaɪd ðə wɛl.

At one farm close by the road a lone chicken scratched in the yard. One barn door swung freely with the wind; the other had broken off the bottom hinge and hung at an angle. The tall house, odd to Rand's Two Rivers eyes, with its sharp-peaked roof of big wooden shingles running almost to the ground, was still and silent. No dog came out to bark at them. A scythe lay in the middle of the barnyard; buckets were overturned in a heap beside the well.

mɔɪɹeɪn fɹaʊn ət ðə fɑɹmhaʊs əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd baɪ. ʃi lɪftəɾ ɑldibz ɹeɪnz, ən ðə waɪt mɛɹ kwɪkən əɹ peɪs.

Moiraine frowned at the farmhouse as they rode by. She lifted Aldieb's reins, and the white mare quickened her pace.

ði ɛmənz fildɝz wɝ klʌstɝd wɪð lɔɪəl ə lɪɾəl bɪhaɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ.

The Emond's Fielders were clustered with Loial a little behind the Aes Sedai and the Warder.

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. hi kəd nɑɾ ɪmædʒən ɛniθɪŋ ɡɹoʊɪŋ ðəɹ ɛvɝ. bʌt ðən i kəd nɑt ɹɪli ɪmædʒən ðə weɪz, iðɝ. ivən naʊ ðəɾ i wɑz pæs ðɛm, hi kəd nɑt.

Rand shook his head. He could not imagine anything growing there ever. But then he could not really imagine the Ways, either. Even now that he was past them, he could not.

"aɪ doʊn θɪŋk ʃi ɪkspɛktəd ðɪs," nɪneɪiv sɛd kwaɪətli, wɪð ə dʒɛstʃɝ ðət tʊk ɪn ɔl ði ɛmpti fɑɹmz ðeɪ hæd sin.

"I don't think she expected this," Nynaeve said quietly, with a gesture that took in all the empty farms they had seen.

"wɛɹ dɪd ðeɪ ɔl ɡoʊ?" ɛɡwin sɛd. "waɪ? ðeɪ kæn əv bɪn ɡɔn vɛɹi lɔŋ."

"Where did they all go?" Egwene said. "Why? They can't have been gone very long."

"wʌt meɪks jə seɪ ðæt?" mæt æskt. "fɹʌm ðə lʊk ə ðət bɑɹn dɔɹ, ðeɪ cʊɾə bɪn ɡɔn ɔl wɪntɝ." nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin boʊθ lʊkt əɾ ɪm əz ɪf i wɝ sloʊ-wɪɾɪd.

"What makes you say that?" Mat asked. "From the look of that barn door, they could have been gone all winter." Nynaeve and Egwene both looked at him as if he were slow-witted.

"ðə kɝɾənz ɪn ðə wɪndoʊz," ɛɡwin sɛd peɪʃənli. "ðeɪ lʊk tu laɪt fəɹ wɪntɝ kɝɾənz, ivən hɪɹ. əz koʊld əz ɪts hɪɹ, noʊ wʊmən wʊɾə hæd ðoʊz ʌp mɔɹ ðən ə wik əɹ tu, meɪbi lɛs." ðə wɪzdəm nɑɾəd.

"The curtains in the windows," Egwene said patiently. "They look too light for winter curtains, even here. As cold as it is here, no woman would have had those up more than a week or two, maybe less." The Wisdom nodded.

"kɝɾənz." pɛɹɪn tʃʌkəld. hi ɪmiɾiətli waɪp ðə smaɪl ɔf ɪz feɪs wən ðə tu wɪmən ɹeɪz ðɛɹ aɪbɹaʊz ət hɪm. "oʊ, aɪ əɡɹi wɪð ju. ðəɹ wɑzn ɪnʌf ɹʌst ɑn ðət saɪð fəɹ ɛni mɔɹ ðən ə wik ɪn ði oʊpən. jə ʃʊɾə sin ðæt, mæt. ivən ɪf jə mɪs ðə kɝɾənz."

"Curtains." Perrin chuckled. He immediately wiped the smile off his face when the two women raised their eyebrows at him. "Oh, I agree with you. There wasn't enough rust on that scythe for any more than a week in the open. You should have seen that, Mat. Even if you missed the curtains."

ɹænd ɡlænst saɪdweɪz ət pɛɹɪn, tʃɹaɪɪŋ nɑt tə stɛɹ. hɪz aɪz wɝ ʃɑɹpɝ ðən pɛɹɪnz - əɹ hæd bɪn, wən ðeɪ juz tə hʌn ɹæbəts təɡɛðɝ - bʌɾ i hæd nɑt bɪn eɪbəl tə si ðət saɪð-bleɪd wɛl ɪnʌf tə meɪk aʊɾ ɛni ɹʌst.
