Rand glanced sideways at Perrin, trying not to stare. His eyes were sharper than Perrin's - or had been, when they used to hunt rabbits together - but he had not been able to see that scythe-blade well enough to make out any rust.

"aɪ ɹɪli doʊn kɛɹ wɛɹ ðeɪ wɛnt," mæt ɡɹʌmbəld. "aɪ dʒʌst wɑnə faɪn sʌmpleɪs wɪð ə faɪɝ. sun."

"I really don't care where they went," Mat grumbled. "I just want to find someplace with a fire. Soon."

"bʌt waɪ dɪd ðeɪ ɡoʊ?" ɹænd sɛɾ ʌndɝ ɪz bɹɛθ. ðə blaɪt wɑz nɑt fɑɹ ɔf hɪɹ. ðə blaɪt, wɛɹ ɔl ðə feɪdz ən tʃɹɑləks wɝ, ðoʊz nɑt daʊn ɪn ændɝ tʃeɪsɪŋ ðɛm. ðə blaɪt, wɛɹ ðeɪ wɝ ɡoʊɪŋ.

"But why did they go?" Rand said under his breath. The Blight was not far off here. The Blight, where all the Fades and Trollocs were, those not down in Andor chasing them. The Blight, where they were going.

hi ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs ɪnʌf tə bi hɝd baɪ ðoʊz kloʊs tə hɪm. "nɪneɪiv, meɪbi jə ən ɛɡwin doʊn əv tə ɡoʊ tə ði aɪ wɪð ʌs." ðə tu wɪmən lʊkt əɾ ɪm əz ɪf i wɝ spikɪŋ ɡɪbɝɪʃ, bʌt wɪð ðə blaɪt soʊ kloʊs i hæd tə meɪk wʌn læs tʃɹaɪ. "meɪbi ɪts ɪnʌf fəɹ jə tə bi kloʊs. mɔɪɹeɪn dɪdn seɪ juv tə ɡoʊ. əɹ ju, lɔɪəl. jə kəd steɪ ət fæl dæɹə. əntɪl wi kʌm bæk. əɹ jə kəd stɑɹt fəɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn. meɪbi ðɛɹəl bi ə mɝtʃən tʃɹeɪn, əɹ əl bɛt mɔɪɹeɪn wəɾ ivən haɪɝ ə koʊtʃ. wɪl miɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, wən ɪts ɔl oʊvɝ."

He raised his voice enough to be heard by those close to him. "Nynaeve, maybe you and Egwene don't have to go to the Eye with us." The two women looked at him as if he were speaking gibberish, but with the Blight so close he had to make one last try. "Maybe it's enough for you to be close. Moiraine didn't say you have to go. Or you, Loial. You could stay at Fal Dara. Until we come back. Or you could start for Tar Valon. Maybe there'll be a merchant train, or I'll bet Moiraine would even hire a coach. We will meet in Tar Valon, when it's all over."

"tɑvɝən." lɔɪəlz saɪ wɑz ə ɹʌmbəl laɪk θʌndɝ ɑn ðə hɝaɪzən. "ju swɝl laɪvz ɝaʊn ju, ɹænd ælθɹ, jə ən jəɹ fɹɛnz. jəɹ feɪt tʃuzəz aʊɝz." ði oʊɡiɝ ʃɹʌɡd, ən sʌɾənli ə bɹɔd ɡɹɪn splɪɾ ɪz feɪs. "bɪsaɪdz, ɪɾəl bi sʌmθɪŋ tə mit ðə ɡɹin mæn. ɛldɝ heɪmən ɔlweɪz tɔks əbaʊɾ ɪz miɾɪŋ wɪð ðə ɡɹin mæn, ən soʊ dʌz maɪ fɑðɝ, ən moʊst ə ði ɛldɝz."

"Ta'veren." Loial's sigh was a rumble like thunder on the horizon. "You swirl lives around you, Rand al'Thor, you and your friends. Your fate chooses ours." The Ogier shrugged, and suddenly a broad grin split his face. "Besides, it will be something to meet the Green Man. Elder Haman always talks about his meeting with the Green Man, and so does my father, and most of the Elders."

"soʊ mɛni?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. "ðə stɔɹiz seɪ ðə ɡɹin mæn ɪz hɑɹd tə faɪnd, ən noʊ wʌn kən faɪn ɪm twaɪs."

"So many?" Perrin said. "The stories say the Green Man is hard to find, and no one can find him twice."

"nɑt twaɪs, noʊ," lɔɪəl əɡɹid. "bʌt ðɛn, aɪ hæv nɛvɝ mɛt hɪm, ən niðɝ əv ju. hi dʌzn sim tə əvɔɪɾ oʊɡiɝ kwaɪt ðə weɪ hi dʌz jə hjumənz. hi noʊz soʊ mʌtʃ əbaʊt tʃɹiz. ivən ðə tʃɹi sɔŋz."

"Not twice, no," Loial agreed. "But then, I have never met him, and neither have you. He doesn't seem to avoid Ogier quite the way he does you humans. He knows so much about trees. Even the Tree Songs."

ɹænd sɛd, "ðə pɔɪn aɪ wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə meɪk ɪz - "

Rand said, "The point I was trying to make is - "

ðə wɪzdəm kʌɾ ɪm ɔf. "ʃi sɛz ɛɡwin ən aɪ ɑɹ pɑɹɾ ə ðə pæɾɝn, tu. ɔl woʊvən ɪn wɪð jə θɹi. ɪf ʃiz tə bi bɪlivd, ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə weɪ ðət pis ə ðə pæɾɝn ɪz woʊvən ðət maɪt stɑp ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ən aɪm əfɹeɪɾ aɪ də bɪliv hɝ; tu mʌtʃ əz hæpənd nɑt tə. bʌɾ ɪf ɛɡwin ən aɪ ɡoʊ əweɪ, wʌt maɪt wi tʃeɪnʒ əbaʊt ðə pæɾɝn?"

The Wisdom cut him off. "She says Egwene and I are part of the Pattern, too. All woven in with you three. If she is to be believed, there's something about the way that piece of the Pattern is woven that might stop the Dark One. And I am afraid I do believe her; too much has happened not to. But if Egwene and I go away, what might we change about the Pattern?"

"aɪ wɑz oʊnli tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə - "

"I was only trying to - "

əɡɛn nɪneɪiv ɪntɝʌptɪd, ʃɑɹpli. "aɪ noʊ wʌt jə wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə du." ʃi lʊkt əɾ ɪm əntɪl i ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, ðən əɹ feɪs sɔfənd. "aɪ noʊ wʌt jə wɝ tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə du, ɹænd. aɪ hæv lɪɾəl laɪkɪŋ fəɹ ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən ðɪs wʌn list ʌv ɔl, aɪ θɪŋk. aɪ hæv lɛs fəɹ ɡoʊɪŋ ɪndə ðə blaɪt, bʌt list ʌv ɔl ɪz ðə laɪkɪŋ aɪ hæv fəɹ ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz. ɪf jə bɔɪz . . . jə mɛn, kən də wʌɾ əz tə bi dʌn wən jud ɹæðɝ də ɔlmoʊst ɛniθɪŋ ɛls, waɪ dʒju θɪŋk əl də lɛs? əɹ ɛɡwin?" ʃi dɪd nɑɾ əpɪɹ tə ɪkspɛkt ən ænsɝ. ɡæðɝɪŋ əɹ ɹeɪnz, ʃi fɹaʊn təwɔɹd ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʌp əhɛd. "aɪ wʌndɝ ɪf wɝ gɑnə ɹitʃ ðɪs fæl dæɹə pleɪs sun, əɹ dʌz ʃi min əs tə spɛn ðə naɪɾ aʊɾ ɪn ðɪs?"

Again Nynaeve interrupted, sharply. "I know what you were trying to do." She looked at him until he shifted uneasily in his saddle, then her face softened. "I know what you were trying to do, Rand. I have little liking for any Aes Sedai, and this one least of all, I think. I have less for going into the Blight, but least of all is the liking I have for the Father of Lies. If you boys . . . you men, can do what has to be done when you'd rather do almost anything else, why do you think I will do less? Or Egwene?" She did not appear to expect an answer. Gathering her reins, she frowned toward the Aes Sedai up ahead. "I wonder if we're going to reach this Fal Dara place soon, or does she mean us to spend the night out in this?"

əz ʃi tʃɹɑɾəd təwɔɹd mɔɪɹeɪn, mæt sɛd, "ʃi kɔld əs mɛn. ɪt simz laɪk oʊnli jɛstɝdeɪ ʃi wɑz seɪɪŋ wi ʃʊdn bi ɔf liɾɪŋ stʃɹɪŋz, ən naʊ ʃi kɔlz əs mɛn."

As she trotted toward Moiraine, Mat said, "She called us men. It seems like only yesterday she was saying we shouldn't be off leading strings, and now she calls us men."

"ju stɪl ʃʊdn bi ɔf jəɹ mʌðɝz eɪpɹən stʃɹɪŋz," ɛɡwin sɛd, bʌt ɹænd dɪd nɑt θɪŋk əɹ hɑɹt wɑz ɪn ɪt. ʃi muv bɛlə kloʊs tə hɪz beɪ, ən loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs soʊ nʌn ə ði ʌðɝz kəd hɪɹ ɔlðoʊ mæt, ət list, tʃɹaɪd. "aɪ oʊnli dænst wɪð ɛɹæm, ɹænd," ʃi sɛd sɔfli, nɑt lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm. "ju wʊdn hoʊld ɪɾ əɡɛns mi, dænsɪŋ wɪð sʌmbɑɾi əl nɛvɝ si əɡɛn, wəd ju?"

"You still shouldn't be off your mother's apron strings," Egwene said, but Rand did not think her heart was in it. She moved Bela close to his bay, and lowered her voice so none of the others could hear although Mat, at least, tried. "I only danced with Aram, Rand," she said softly, not looking at him. "You wouldn't hold it against me, dancing with somebody I will never see again, would you?"

"noʊ," hi toʊl hɝ. wʌt hæd meɪɾ əɹ bɹɪŋ ɪɾ ʌp naʊ? "ʌv kɔɹs nɑt." bʌt sʌɾənli hi ɹɪmɛmbɝd sʌmθɪŋ mɪn hæd sɛɾ ɪn bɛɹlən, wʌt simd ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz əɡoʊ. ʃiz nɑt fəɹ ju, nɔɹ jə fəɹ hɝ; ət list, nɑɾ ɪn ðə weɪ jə boʊθ wɑnt.

"No," he told her. What had made her bring it up now? "Of course not." But suddenly he remembered something Min had said in Baerlon, what seemed a hundred years ago. She's not for you, nor you for her; at least, not in the way you both want.

ðə taʊn ə fæl dæɹə wɑz bɪlt ɑn hɪlz haɪɝ ðən ðə sɝaʊndɪŋ kʌntʃɹi. ɪt wɑz noʊwɛɹ nɪɹ əz bɪɡ əz keɪɛmlɪn, bʌt ðə wɔl ɝaʊn ɪt wɑz əz haɪ əz keɪɛmlɪnz. fəɹ ə fʊl maɪl aʊtsaɪd ðət wɔl ɪn ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɑz klɪɹ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ tɔlɝ ðən ɡɹæs, ən ðət kʌt loʊ. nʌθɪŋ kəd kʌm kloʊs wɪθaʊt biɪŋ sin fɹəm wʌn ə ðə mɛni tɔl taʊɝz tɑp baɪ wʊɾən hɔɹɾɪŋz. wɛɹ ðə wɔlz ə keɪɛmlɪn hæɾ ə bjuɾi əbaʊt ðɛm, ðə bɪldɝz ə fæl dæɹə sim nɑt tə hæv kɛɹɾ ɪf ɛniwʌn faʊn ðɛɹ wɔl bjuɾəfəl. ðə ɡɹeɪ stoʊn wɑz ɡɹɪmli ɪmplækəbəl, pɹoʊkleɪmɪŋ ðəɾ ɪɾ ɪɡzɪstəd fəɹ wʌn pɝpəs əloʊn: tə hoʊld. pɛnəns ətɑp ðə hɔɹɾɪŋz wɪpt ɪn ðə wɪnd, meɪkɪŋ ðə stupɪŋ blæk hɔk ə ʃaɪnɝ sim tə flaɪ ɔl əlɔŋ ðə wɔlz.

The town of Fal Dara was built on hills higher than the surrounding country. It was nowhere near as big as Caemlyn, but the wall around it was as high as Caemlyn's. For a full mile outside that wall in every direction the ground was clear of anything taller than grass, and that cut low. Nothing could come close without being seen from one of the many tall towers topped by wooden hoardings. Where the walls of Caemlyn had a beauty about them, the builders of Fal Dara seemed not to have cared if anyone found their wall beautiful. The gray stone was grimly implacable, proclaiming that it existed for one purpose alone: to hold. Pennants atop the hoardings whipped in the wind, making the stooping Black Hawk of Shienar seem to fly all along the walls.

læn tɔs bæk ðə hʊɾ ə hɪz kloʊk ænd, dɪspaɪt ðə koʊld, moʊʃən fəɹ ði ʌðɝz tə də ðə seɪm. mɔɪɹeɪn hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi loʊɝd hɝz. "ɪts ðə lɔ ɪn ʃaɪnɝ," ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd. "ɪn ɔl ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. noʊ wʌn meɪ haɪɾ ɪz feɪs ɪnsaɪɾ ə taʊnz wɔlz."

Lan tossed back the hood of his cloak and, despite the cold, motioned for the others to do the same. Moiraine had already lowered hers. "It's the law in Shienar," the Warder said. "In all the Borderlands. No one may hide his face inside a town's walls."

"ɑɹ ðeɪ ɔl ðət ɡʊd-lʊkɪŋ?" mæt læft.

"Are they all that good-looking?" Mat laughed.

"eɪ hæfmən kæn haɪd wɪð ɪz feɪs ɪkspoʊzd," ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛɾ ɪn ə flæt vɔɪs.

"A Halfman can't hide with his face exposed," the Warder said in a flat voice.

ɹændz ɡɹɪn slɪɾ ɔf ɪz feɪs. heɪstəli mæt pʊʃt bæk ɪz hʊd.

Rand's grin slid off his face. Hastily Mat pushed back his hood.

ðə ɡeɪts stʊɾ oʊpən, tɔl ən kʌvɝd wɪð dɑɹk aɪɝn, bʌɾ ə dʌzən ɑɹmɝd mɛn stʊd ɡɑɹɾ ɪn ɡoʊldən jɛloʊ sɝkoʊts bɛɹɪŋ ðə blæk hɔk. ðə hɪls ə lɔŋ sɔɹdz ɑn ðɛɹ bæks pikt oʊvɝ ðɛɹ ʃoʊldɝz, ən bɹɔdsɔɹɾ əɹ meɪs əɹ æks hʌŋ əɾ ɛvɹi weɪst. ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz wɝ tɛðɝd nɪɹbaɪ, meɪd ɡɹoʊtɛsk baɪ ðə stil bɑɹɾɪŋz kʌvɝɪŋ tʃɛsts ən nɛks ən hɛdz, wɪð lænsɪz tə stɝəp, ɔl ɹɛɾi tə ɹaɪɾ əɾ ən ɪnstənt. ðə ɡɑɹdz meɪd noʊ muv tə stɑp læn ən mɔɪɹeɪn ən ði ʌðɝz. ɪndid, ðeɪ weɪvd ən kɔld aʊt hæpəli.

The gates stood open, tall and covered with dark iron, but a dozen armored men stood guard in golden yellow surcoats bearing the Black Hawk. The hilts of long swords on their backs peeked over their shoulders, and broadsword or mace or axe hung at every waist. Their horses were tethered nearby, made grotesque by the steel bardings covering chests and necks and heads, with lances to stirrup, all ready to ride at an instant. The guards made no move to stop Lan and Moiraine and the others. Indeed, they waved and called out happily.

"daɪ ʃæn!" wʌn kɹaɪd, ʃeɪkɪŋ stil-ɡɔntələɾəd fɪsts oʊvɝ ɪz hɛɾ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd pæst. "daɪ ʃæn!"

"Dai Shan!" one cried, shaking steel-gauntleted fists over his head as they rode past. "Dai Shan!"

ə nʌmbɝ ʌv ʌðɝz ʃaʊɾəd, "ɡlɔɹi tə ðə bɪldɝz!" ænd, "kaɪsɝi ti wɑnʃoʊ!" lɔɪəl lʊk sɝpɹaɪzd, ðən ə bɹɔd smaɪl splɪɾ ɪz feɪs ən i weɪv tə ðə ɡɑɹdz.

A number of others shouted, "Glory to the Builders!" and, "Kiserai ti Wansho!" Loial looked surprised, then a broad smile split his face and he waved to the guards.

wʌn mæn ɹæn əlɔŋsaɪd lænz hɔɹs ə lɪɾəl weɪ, ənhæmpɝd baɪ ði ɑɹmɝ i wɔɹ. "wɪl ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn flaɪ əɡɛn, daɪ ʃæn?"

One man ran alongside Lan's horse a little way, unhampered by the armor he wore. "Will the Golden Crane fly again, Dai Shan?"

"pis, ɹeɪɡən," wɑz ɔl ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd, ən ðə mæn fɛl əweɪ. hi ɹɪtɝn ðə ɡɑɹdz' weɪvz, bʌɾ ɪz feɪs wɑz sʌɾənli ivən mɔɹ ɡɹɪm.

"Peace, Ragan," was all the Warder said, and the man fell away. He returned the guards' waves, but his face was suddenly even more grim.

əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd θɹu stoʊn-peɪv stʃɹits kɹaʊɾəd wɪð pipəl ən wæɡənz, ɹænd fɹaʊnd wɝidli. fæl dæɹə wɑz bʌlʒɪŋ ət ðə simz, bʌt ðə pipəl wɝ niðɝ ði iɡɝ kɹaʊdz ə keɪɛmlɪn, ɛndʒɔɪɪŋ ðə ɡɹænduɹ ə ðə sɪɾi ivən əz ðeɪ skwɑbəld, nɔɹ ðə mɪlɪŋ θɹɔŋz ə bɛɹlən. pæk tʃik baɪ dʒaʊl, ðiz foʊk wɑtʃt ðɛɹ pɑɹɾi ɹaɪd baɪ wɪð lɛɾən aɪz ən feɪsəz blæŋkt ʌv ɪmoʊʃən. kɑɹts ən wæɡənz dʒæmd ɛvɹi æliweɪ ən hæf ðə stʃɹits, paɪl haɪ wɪð dʒʌmbəl haʊshoʊl fɝnɪʃɪŋz, ən kɑɹv tʃɛsts pæk soʊ taɪt ðət kloʊðz spɪld. ɑn tɑp sæt ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ədʌls kɛp ðə jʌŋɡəlɪŋz ʌp wɛɹ ðeɪ kəd bi sin ən dɪd nɑt lɛɾ əm stʃɹeɪ ivən tə pleɪ. ðə tʃɪlʒɹən wɝ ivən mɔɹ saɪlən ðən ðɛɹ ɛldɝz, ðɛɹ aɪz bɪɡɝ, mɔɹ hɔntɪŋ ɪn ðɛɹ stɛɹz. ðə nʊks ən kɹæniz bɪtwin ðə wæɡənz wɝ fɪld wɪð ʃæɡi kæɾəl ən blæk-spɑɾəd pɪɡz ɪn meɪkʃɪf pɛnz. kɹeɪts ə tʃɪkənz ən dʌks ən ɡis fɪtfəli meɪɾ ʌp fəɹ ðə saɪləns ə ðə pipəl. hi nu naʊ wɛɹ ɔl ðə fɑɹmɝz hæd ɡɔn.

As they rode through stone-paved streets crowded with people and wagons, Rand frowned worriedly. Fal Dara was bulging at the seams, but the people were neither the eager crowds of Caemlyn, enjoying the grandeur of the city even as they squabbled, nor the milling throngs of Baerlon. Packed cheek by jowl, these folk watched their party ride by with leaden eyes and faces blanked of emotion. Carts and wagons jammed every alleyway and half the streets, piled high with jumbled household furnishings, and carved chests packed so tight that clothes spilled. On top sat the children. Adults kept the younglings up where they could be seen and did not let them stray even to play. The children were even more silent than their elders, their eyes bigger, more haunting in their stares. The nooks and crannies between the wagons were filled with shaggy cattle and black-spotted pigs in makeshift pens. Crates of chickens and ducks and geese fitfully made up for the silence of the people. He knew now where all the farmers had gone.

læn lɛd ðə weɪ tə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə taʊn, ə mæsɪv stoʊn paɪl ətɑp ðə haɪəs hɪl. ə dʒɹaɪ moʊt, dip ən waɪd, ɪts bɑɾəm ə fɔɹəst ə ʃɑɹp stil spaɪks, ɹeɪzɝ-ɛdʒd ən əz tɔl əz ə mæn, sɝaʊndəd ðə taʊɝd wɔlz ə ðə kip. ə pleɪs fəɹ ə læs dɪfɛns, ɪf ðə ɹɛst ə ðə taʊn fɛl. fɹəm wʌn ə ðə ɡeɪt taʊɝz ən ɑɹmɝd mæn kɔl daʊn, "wɛlkəm, daɪ ʃæn." ənʌðɝ ʃaʊɾəd tə ði ɪnsaɪɾ ə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs, "ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn! ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn!"

Lan led the way to the fortress in the middle of the town, a massive stone pile atop the highest hill. A dry moat, deep and wide, its bottom a forest of sharp steel spikes, razor-edged and as tall as a man, surrounded the towered walls of the keep. A place for a last defense, if the rest of the town fell. From one of the gate towers an armored man called down, "Welcome, Dai Shan." Another shouted to the inside of the fortress, "The Golden Crane! The Golden Crane!"

ðɛɹ hʊvz dʒɹʌmd ɑn ðə hɛvi tɪmbɝz ə ðə loʊɝd dʒɹɔbɹɪdʒ əz ðeɪ kɹɔs ðə moʊɾ ən ɹoʊɾ ʌndɝ ðə ʃɑɹp pɔɪns ə ðə staʊt pɔɹtkʌlɪs. wʌns θɹu ðə ɡeɪts, læn swʌŋ daʊn aʊɾ ə hɪz sæɾəl tə lid mændɑɹb, sɪɡnəlɪŋ ði ʌðɝz tə dɪsmaʊnt.

Their hooves drummed on the heavy timbers of the lowered drawbridge as they crossed the moat and rode under the sharp points of the stout portcullis. Once through the gates, Lan swung down out of his saddle to lead Mandarb, signaling the others to dismount.

ðə fɝs kɔɹtʃjɑɹd wɑz ə hjudʒ skwɛɹ peɪvd wɪð bɪɡ stoʊn blɑks ən sɝaʊndəd baɪ taʊɝz ən bæɾəlmənts əz fɪɹs əz ðoʊz ɑn ði aʊtsaɪɾ ə ðə wɔlz. əz bɪɡ əz ɪt wɑz, ðə kɔɹtʃjɑɹɾ əpɪɹd dʒʌst əz kɹaʊɾəd əz ðə stʃɹits, ən əz mʌtʃ ɪn tɝmɔɪl, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz ən ɔɹɾɝ tə ðə kɹaʊɾɪŋ hɪɹ. ɛvɹiwɛɹ wɝ ɑɹmɝd mɛn ən ɑɹmɝd hɔɹsəz. ət hæf ə dʌzən smɪθiz ɝaʊn ðə kɔɹt, hæmɝz klæŋd, ən bɪɡ bɛloʊz, tʌɡd baɪ tu lɛðɝ-eɪpɹən mɛn əpis, meɪd ðə fɔɹdʒ-faɪɝz ɹɔɹ. ə stɛɾi stʃɹim ə bɔɪz ɹæn wɪð nu-meɪd hɔɹs ʃuz fəɹ ðə fɛɹiɝz. flɛtʃɝz sæt meɪkɪŋ æɹoʊz, ən ɛvɹi taɪm ə bæskət wɑz fɪld ɪt wɑz wɪskt əweɪ ən ɹipleɪst wɪð ən ɛmpti wʌn.

The first courtyard was a huge square paved with big stone blocks and surrounded by towers and battlements as fierce as those on the outside of the walls. As big as it was, the courtyard appeared just as crowded as the streets, and as much in turmoil, though there was an order to the crowding here. Everywhere were armored men and armored horses. At half a dozen smithies around the court, hammers clanged, and big bellows, tugged by two leather-aproned men apiece, made the forge-fires roar. A steady stream of boys ran with new-made horse shoes for the farriers. Fletchers sat making arrows, and every time a basket was filled it was whisked away and replaced with an empty one.

lɪvɹid ɡɹumz əpɪɹɾ ɑn ðə ɹʌn, iɡɝ ən smaɪlɪŋ ɪn blæk-ænd-ɡoʊld. ɹænd heɪstəli əntaɪɾ ɪz bɪlɔŋɪŋz fɹəm bɪhaɪn ðə sæɾəl ən ɡeɪv ðə beɪ ʌp tə wʌn ə ðə ɡɹumz əz ə mæn ɪn pleɪt-ænd-meɪl ən lɛðɝ baʊd fɔɹməli. hi wɔɹ ə bɹaɪt jɛloʊ kloʊk ɛdʒd ɪn ɹɛɾ oʊvɝ ɪz ɑɹmɝ, wɪð ðə blæk hɔk ɑn ðə bɹɛst, ən ə jɛloʊ sɝkoʊt bɛɹɪŋ ə ɡɹeɪ aʊl. hi wɔɹ noʊ hɛlməɾ ən wɑz bæɹhɛɾɪd, tʃɹuli, fəɹ ɪz hɛɹ hæɾ ɔl bɪn ʃeɪvd ɪksɛp fəɹ ə tɑpnɑt taɪd wɪð ə lɛðɝ kɔɹd. "ɪɾ əz bɪn lɔŋ, mɔɪɹeɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɪts ɡʊd tə si ju, daɪ ʃæn. vɛɹi ɡʊd." hi baʊɾ əɡɛn, tə lɔɪəl, ən mɝmɝd, "ɡlɔɹi tə ðə bɪldɝz. kaɪsɝi ti wɑnʃoʊ."

Liveried grooms appeared on the run, eager and smiling in black-and-gold. Rand hastily untied his belongings from behind the saddle and gave the bay up to one of the grooms as a man in plate-and-mail and leather bowed formally. He wore a bright yellow cloak edged in red over his armor, with the Black Hawk on the breast, and a yellow surcoat bearing a gray owl. He wore no helmet and was bareheaded, truly, for his hair had all been shaved except for a topknot tied with a leather cord. "It has been long, Moiraine Aes Sedai. It is good to see you, Dai Shan. Very good." He bowed again, to Loial, and murmured, "Glory to the Builders. Kiserai ti Wansho."

"aɪ æm ənwɝði," lɔɪəl ɹɪplaɪd fɔɹməli, "æn ðə wɝk smɔl. tsɪŋɡʌ mɑ tʃoʊbə."

"I am unworthy," Loial replied formally, "and the work small. Tsingu ma choba."

"ju ɑnɝ ʌs, bɪldɝ," ðə mæn sɛd. "kaɪsɝi ti wɑnʃoʊ." hi tɝn bæk tə læn. "wɝd wɑz sɛn tə lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ, daɪ ʃæn, əz sun əz jə wɝ sin kʌmɪŋ. hiz weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ju. ðɪs weɪ, pliz."

"You honor us, Builder," the man said. "Kiserai ti Wansho." He turned back to Lan. "Word was sent to Lord Agelmar, Dai Shan, as soon as you were seen coming. He is waiting for you. This way, please."

əz ðeɪ fɑloʊɾ ɪm ɪndə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs, əlɔŋ dʒɹæfti stoʊn kɔɹɪɾɝz hʌŋ wɪð kʌlɝfəl tæpəstʃɹiz ən lɔŋ sɪlk skɹinz ə hʌntɪŋ sinz ən bæɾəlz, hi kəntɪnjud. "aɪ æm ɡlæd ðə kɔl ɹitʃt ju, daɪ ʃæn. wɪl jə ɹeɪz ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn bænɝ wʌns mɔɹ?" ðə hɔlz wɝ stɑɹk ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə wɔl hæŋʒɪŋz, ən ivən ðeɪ juz ðə fjuəs fɪɡjɝz meɪd wɪð ðə fjuəs laɪnz nɛsəsɛɹi tə kənveɪ minɪŋ, ðoʊ ɪn bɹaɪt kʌlɝz.

As they followed him into the fortress, along drafty stone corridors hung with colorful tapestries and long silk screens of hunting scenes and battles, he continued. "I am glad the call reached you, Dai Shan. Will you raise the Golden Crane banner once more?" The halls were stark except for the wall hangings, and even they used the fewest figures made with the fewest lines necessary to convey meaning, though in bright colors.

"ɑɹ θɪŋz ɹɪli əz bæɾ əz ðeɪ əpɪɹ, ɪŋtʃɹ?" læn æskt kwaɪətli. ɹænd wʌndɝɾ ɪf ɪz oʊn ɪɹz wɝ twɪtʃɪŋ laɪk lɔɪəlz.

"Are things really as bad as they appear, Ingtar?" Lan asked quietly. Rand wondered if his own ears were twitching like Loial's.

ðə mænz tɑpnɑt sweɪɾ əz i ʃʊk ɪz hɛd, bʌɾ i hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ pʊɾɪŋ ɑn ə ɡɹɪn. "θɪŋz ɑɹ nɛvɝ əz bæɾ əz ðeɪ əpɪɹ, daɪ ʃæn. ə lɪɾəl wɝs ðən juʒəwəl ðɪs jɪɹ, ðəɾ ɪz ɔl. ðə ɹeɪdz kəntɪnjud θɹu ðə wɪntɝ, ivən ɪn ðə hɑɹɾəst ʌv ɪt. bʌt ðə ɹeɪɾɪŋ wɑz noʊ wɝs ðən ɛniwɛɹ ɛls əlɔŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝ. ðeɪ stɪl kʌm ɪn ðə naɪt, bʌt wʌɾ ɛls kən bi ɪkspɛktəɾ ɪn ðə spɹɪŋ, ɪf ðɪs kən bi kɔl spɹɪŋ. skaʊts ɹɪtɝn fɹəm ðə blaɪt - ðoʊz u də kʌm bæk - wɪð nuz ə tʃɹɑlɑk kæmps. ɔlweɪz fɹɛʃ nuz ə mɔɹ kæmps. bʌt wɪl miɾ əm ət tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp, daɪ ʃæn, ən tɝn əm bæk əz wi ɔlweɪz hæv."

The man's topknot swayed as he shook his head, but he hesitated before putting on a grin. "Things are never as bad as they appear, Dai Shan. A little worse than usual this year, that is all. The raids continued through the winter, even in the hardest of it. But the raiding was no worse than anywhere else along the Border. They still come in the night, but what else can be expected in the spring, if this can be called spring. Scouts return from the Blight - those who do come back - with news of Trolloc camps. Always fresh news of more camps. But we will meet them at Tarwin's Gap, Dai Shan, and turn them back as we always have."

"ʌv kɔɹs," læn sɛd, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt saʊn sɝɾən.

"Of course," Lan said, but he did not sound certain.

ɪŋtʃɹz ɡɹɪn slɪpt, bʌt keɪm bæk ɪmiɾiətli. saɪlənli hi ʃoʊɾ əm ɪndə lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝz stʌɾi, ðən kleɪm ðə pɹɛs ə hɪz duɾiz ən lɛft.

Ingtar's grin slipped, but came back immediately. Silently he showed them into Lord Agelmar's study, then claimed the press of his duties and left.

ɪt wɑz ə ɹum əz pɝpəs-meɪɾ əz ɔl ðə ɹɛst ə ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs, wɪð æɹoʊslɪts ɪn ði aʊɾɝ wɔl ən ə hɛvi bɑɹ fəɹ ðə θɪk dɔɹ, wɪtʃ hæɾ ɪts oʊn æɹoʊpjɹsɪŋz ən wɑz baʊn baɪ aɪɝn stʃɹæps. oʊnli wʌn tæpəstʃɹi hʌŋ hɪɹ. ɪt kʌvɝɾ ən ɪntaɪɝ wɔl ən ʃoʊd mɛn, ɑɹmɝd laɪk ðə mɛn ə fæl dæɹə, faɪɾɪŋ mɹdʒɹɑl ən tʃɹɑləks ɪn ə maʊntən pæs.

It was a room as purpose-made as all the rest of the fortress, with arrowslits in the outer wall and a heavy bar for the thick door, which had its own arrowpiercings and was bound by iron straps. Only one tapestry hung here. It covered an entire wall and showed men, armored like the men of Fal Dara, fighting Myrddraal and Trollocs in a mountain pass.

ə teɪbəl, wʌn tʃɛst, ən ə fju tʃɛɹz wɝ ði oʊnli fɝnɪʃɪŋz ɪksɛp fəɹ tu ɹæks ɑn ðə wɔl, ən ðeɪ kɑt ɹændz aɪ əz mʌtʃ əz ðə tæpəstʃɹi. wʌn hɛld ə tu-hændəd sɔɹd, tɔlɝ ðən ə mæn, ə mɔɹ ɔɹɾənɛɹi bɹɔdsɔɹd, ən bɪloʊ ðɛm ə stʌɾɪd meɪs ən ə lɔŋ, kaɪt-ʃeɪpt ʃil bɛɹɪŋ θɹi fɑksəz. fɹəm ði ʌðɝ hʌŋ ə suɾ ʌv ɑɹmɝ, kəmpliɾ ən ɝeɪnʒd əz wʌn wəd wɛɹ ɪt. kɹɛstəd hɛlmət wɪð ɪts bɑɹd feɪsɡɑɹɾ oʊvɝ ə dʌbəl-meɪl kɑmeɪl. meɪl haʊbɹk, splɪt fəɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ, ən lɛðɝ ʌndɝkoʊt, pɑlɪʃt fɹəm wɛɹ. bɹɛstpleɪt, stil ɡɔnləts, ni ən ɛlboʊ kɑps, ən hæf-pleɪt fəɹ ʃoʊldɝz ən ɑɹmz ən lɛɡz. ivən hɪɹ ɪn ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə kip, wɛpənz ən ɑɹmɝ simd ɹɛɾi tə bi dɑn əɾ ɛni moʊmənt. laɪk ðə fɝnɪtʃɝ, ðeɪ wɝ sɪmpli ən səvɪɹli dɛkɝeɪɾəd wɪð ɡoʊld.

A table, one chest, and a few chairs were the only furnishings except for two racks on the wall, and they caught Rand's eye as much as the tapestry. One held a two-handed sword, taller than a man, a more ordinary broadsword, and below them a studded mace and a long, kite-shaped shield bearing three foxes. From the other hung a suit of armor, complete and arranged as one would wear it. Crested helmet with its barred faceguard over a double-mail camail. Mail hauberk, split for riding, and leather undercoat, polished from wear. Breastplate, steel gauntlets, knee and elbow cops, and half-plate for shoulders and arms and legs. Even here in the heart of the Keep, weapons and armor seemed ready to be donned at any moment. Like the furniture, they were simply and severely decorated with gold.

eɪɡəlmɝ hɪmsɛlf ɹoʊz ət ðɛɹ ɛntʃɹəns ən keɪm ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl, lɪɾɝd wɪð mæps ən ʃifs ə peɪpɝ ən pɛnz stændɪŋ ɪn ɪŋkpɑts. hi simd ət fɝst ɡlæns tu pisfəl fəɹ ðə ɹum ɪn ɪz blu vɛlvət koʊt wɪð ɪts tɔl, waɪd kɑlɝ, ən sɑf lɛðɝ buts, bʌɾ ə sɛkən lʊk ʃoʊd ɹænd dɪfɹənli. laɪk ɔl ðə faɪɾɪŋ mɛn i hæd sin, eɪɡəlmɝz hɛd wɑz ʃeɪvd ɪksɛp fəɹ ə tɑpnɑt, ən ðət pjʊɹ waɪt. hɪz feɪs wɑz əz hɑɹɾ əz lænz, ði oʊnli laɪnz kɹisɪz ət ðə kɔɹnɝz ə hɪz aɪz, ən ðoʊz aɪz laɪk bɹaʊn stoʊn, ðoʊ ðeɪ bɔɹ ə smaɪl naʊ.

Agelmar himself rose at their entrance and came around the table, littered with maps and sheafs of paper and pens standing in inkpots. He seemed at first glance too peaceful for the room in his blue velvet coat with its tall, wide collar, and soft leather boots, but a second look showed Rand differently. Like all the fighting men he had seen, Agelmar's head was shaved except for a topknot, and that pure white. His face was as hard as Lan's, the only lines creases at the corners of his eyes, and those eyes like brown stone, though they bore a smile now.

"pis, bʌɾ ɪts ɡʊd tə si ju, daɪ ʃæn," ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə sɛd. "æn ju, mɔɪɹeɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ, pɝhæps ivən mɔɹ. jəɹ pɹɛzəns wɔɹmz mi, ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Peace, but it is good to see you, Dai Shan," the Lord of Fal Dara said. "And you, Moiraine Aes Sedai, perhaps even more. Your presence warms me, Aes Sedai."

"naɪn kəlɪknaɪi noʊ dəmæʃiɾə, eɪɡəlmɝ daɪ ʃæn," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd fɔɹməli, bʌt wɪð ə noʊɾ ɪn əɹ vɔɪs ðət sɛd ðeɪ wɝ oʊl fɹɛnz. "jɔɹ wɛlkəm wɔɹmz mi, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ."

"Ninte calichniye no domashita, Agelmar Dai Shan," Moiraine replied formally, but with a note in her voice that said they were old friends. "Your welcome warms me, Lord Agelmar."

"koʊdoʊm kəlɪknaɪi ɡɑ ni ɛɛs sədaɪ heɪ. hɪɹ ɪz ɔlweɪz ə wɛlkəm fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ." hi tɝn tə lɔɪəl. "ju ɑɹ fɑɹ fɹəm ðə stɛɾɪŋ, oʊɡiɝ, bʌt jə ɑnɝ fæl dæɹə. ɔlweɪz ɡlɔɹi tə ðə bɪldɝz. kaɪsɝi ti wɑnʃoʊ heɪ."

"Kodome calichniye ga ni Aes Sedai hei. Here is always a welcome for Aes Sedai." He turned to Loial. "You are far from the stedding, Ogier, but you honor Fal Dara. Always glory to the Builders. Kiserai ti Wansho hei."

"aɪ æm ənwɝði," lɔɪəl sɛd, boʊɪŋ. "ɪɾ ɪz jə hu də mi ɑnɝ." hi ɡlænst ət ðə stɑɹk stoʊn wɔlz ən sim tə stʃɹʌɡəl wɪð hɪmsɛlf. ɹænd wɑz ɡlæd ði oʊɡiɝ mænədʒ tə ɹɪfɹeɪn fɹəm æɾɪŋ fɝðɝ kɑmɛnt.

"I am unworthy," Loial said, bowing. "It is you who do me honor." He glanced at the stark stone walls and seemed to struggle with himself. Rand was glad the Ogier managed to refrain from adding further comment.

sɝvəns ɪn blæk-ænd-ɡoʊld əpɪɹɾ ɑn saɪlənt, sɑft-slɪpɝd fit. səm bɹɔt foʊldəd klɔθs, dæmp ən hɑt, ɑn sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪz fəɹ waɪpɪŋ ðə dʌs fɹəm feɪsəz ən hænz. ʌðɝz bɔɹ mʌld waɪn ən sɪlvɝ boʊlz ə dʒɹaɪd plʌmz ən æpɹəkɑts. lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ ɡeɪv ɔɹɾɝz fəɹ ɹumz tə bi pɹipɛɹd, ən bæθs.

Servants in black-and-gold appeared on silent, soft-slippered feet. Some brought folded cloths, damp and hot, on silver trays for wiping the dust from faces and hands. Others bore mulled wine and silver bowls of dried plums and apricots. Lord Agelmar gave orders for rooms to be prepared, and baths.

"ə lɔŋ dʒɝni fɹəm tɑɹ vəlɑn," hi sɛd. "ju mʌs bi taɪɝd."

"A long journey from Tar Valon," he said. "You must be tired."

"ə ʃɔɹt dʒɝni ðə pæθ wi keɪm," læn toʊl hɪm, "bʌt mɔɹ taɪɹɪŋ ðən ðə lɔŋ weɪ."

"A short journey the path we came," Lan told him, "but more tiring than the long way."

eɪɡəlmɝ lʊk pʌzəld wən ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd noʊ mɔɹ, bʌɾ i mɪɹli sɛd, "ə fju deɪz' ɹɛst wɪl pʊt jə ɔl ɪn faɪn fɛɾəl."

Agelmar looked puzzled when the Warder said no more, but he merely said, "A few days' rest will put you all in fine fettle."

"aɪ æsk wʌn naɪts ʃɛltɝ, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "fɔɹ aʊɝsɛlvz ən əɹ hɔɹsəz. ən fɹɛʃ səplaɪz ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ, ɪf jə kən spɛɹ ðɛm. wi mʌs liv jə ɝli, aɪm əfɹeɪd."

"I ask one night's shelter, Lord Agelmar," Moiraine said, "for ourselves and our horses. And fresh supplies in the morning, if you can spare them. We must leave you early, I am afraid."

eɪɡəlmɝ fɹaʊnd. "bʌɾ aɪ θɔt. . . . mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ, aɪ hæv noʊ ɹaɪt tə æsk ɪɾ ə ju, bʌt jə wəd bi wɝθ ə θaʊzən lænsɪz ɪn tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp. ən ju, daɪ ʃæn. ə θaʊzən mɛn wɪl kʌm wən ðeɪ hɪɹ ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn flaɪz wʌns mɔɹ."

Agelmar frowned. "But I thought. . . . Moiraine Sedai, I have no right to ask it of you, but you would be worth a thousand lances in Tarwin's Gap. And you, Dai Shan. A thousand men will come when they hear the Golden Crane flies once more."

"ðə sɛvən taʊɝz ɑɹ bɹoʊkən," læn sɛd hɑɹʃli, "æn mɔlkiɝ ɪz dɛd; ðə fju ʌv əɹ pipəl lɛft, skæɾɝd əkɹɔs ðə feɪs ə ði ɝθ. aɪm ə wɔɹɾɝ, eɪɡəlmɝ, swɔɹn tə ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ən aɪm baʊn ɪndə ðə blaɪt."

"The Seven Towers are broken," Lan said harshly, "and Malkier is dead; the few of her people left, scattered across the face of the earth. I am a Warder, Agelmar, sworn to the Flame of Tar Valon, and I am bound into the Blight."

"ʌv kɔɹs, daɪ  - læn. ʌv kɔɹs. bʌt ʃʊɹli ə fju deɪz' dɪleɪ, ə fju wiks ət moʊst, wɪl meɪk noʊ dɪfɝəns. jə ɑɹ niɾəd. ju, ən mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ."

"Of course, Dai Sh - Lan. Of course. But surely a few days' delay, a few weeks at most, will make no difference. You are needed. You, and Moiraine Sedai."

mɔɪɹeɪn tʊk ə sɪlvɝ ɡɑblət fɹəm wʌn ə ðə sɝvəns. "ɪŋtʃɹ simz tə bɪliv jəl dɪfit ðɪs θɹɛɾ əz juv dɪfiɾəd mɛni ʌðɝz əkɹɔs ðə jɪɹz."

Moiraine took a silver goblet from one of the servants. "Ingtar seems to believe you will defeat this threat as you have defeated many others across the years."

"ɛɛs sədaɪ," eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd ɹaɪli, "ɪf ɪŋtʃɹ hæd tə ɹaɪɾ əloʊn tə tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp, hi wəd ɹaɪd ðə hoʊl weɪ pɹoʊkleɪmɪŋ ðət ðə tʃɹɑləks wəd bi tɝn bæk wʌns mɔɹ. hiz ɔlmoʊs pɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf tə bɪliv i kəd də ɪɾ əloʊn."

"Aes Sedai," Agelmar said wryly, "if Ingtar had to ride alone to Tarwin's Gap, he would ride the whole way proclaiming that the Trollocs would be turned back once more. He has almost pride enough to believe he could do it alone."

"hi ɪz nɑɾ əz kɑnfəɾənt əz jə θɪŋk, ðɪs taɪm, eɪɡəlmɝ." ðə wɔɹɾɝ hɛld ə kʌp, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt dʒɹɪŋk. "haʊ bæɾ ɪz ɪt?"

"He is not as confident as you think, this time, Agelmar." The Warder held a cup, but he did not drink. "How bad is it?"

eɪɡəlmɝ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, pʊlɪŋ ə mæp fɹəm ðə tæŋɡəl ɑn ðə teɪbəl. hi stɛɹɾ ənsiɪŋ ət ðə mæp fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðən tɔst ɪt bæk. "wɛn wi ɹaɪd tə ðə ɡæp," hi sɛd kwaɪətli, "ðə pipəl wɪl bi sɛn saʊθ tə fæl mɝæn. pɝhæps ðə kæpəɾəl kən hoʊld. pis, ɪt mʌst. sʌmθɪŋ mʌs hoʊld."

Agelmar hesitated, pulling a map from the tangle on the table. He stared unseeing at the map for a moment, then tossed it back. "When we ride to the Gap," he said quietly, "the people will be sent south to Fal Moran. Perhaps the capital can hold. Peace, it must. Something must hold."

"ðæt bæd?" læn sɛd, ən eɪɡəlmɝ nɑɾəd wɛɹəli.

"That bad?" Lan said, and Agelmar nodded wearily.

ɹænd ɪkstʃeɪnʒd wɝid lʊks wɪð mæt ən pɛɹɪn. ɪt wɑz izi tə bɪliv ðə tʃɹɑləks ɡæðɝɪŋ ɪn ðə blaɪt wɝ æftɝ hɪm, æftɝ ðɛm. eɪɡəlmɝ wɛn ɑn ɡɹɪmli.

Rand exchanged worried looks with Mat and Perrin. It was easy to believe the Trollocs gathering in the Blight were after him, after them. Agelmar went on grimly.

"kændɝ, ɝæfəl, sɑldɑiə - ðə tʃɹɑləks ɹeɪɾɪd əm ɔl stʃɹeɪt θɹu ðə wɪntɝ. nʌθɪŋ laɪk ðəɾ əz hæpən sɪns ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz; ðə ɹeɪdz əv nɛvɝ bɪn soʊ fɪɹs, əɹ soʊ lɑɹdʒ, əɹ pɹɛs hoʊm soʊ hɑɹd. ɛvɹi kɪŋ ən kaʊnsəl ɪz ʃʊɹ ə ɡɹeɪt θɹʌst ɪz kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə blaɪt, ən ɛvɹi wʌn ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz bɪlivz ɪts kʌmɪŋ ət ðɛm. nʌn ə ðɛɹ skaʊts, ən nʌn ə ðə wɔɹɾɝz, ɹipɔɹt tʃɹɑlɑk mæsɪŋ əbʌv ðɛɹ bɔɹɾɝz, əz wɪv hɪɹ, bʌt ðeɪ bɪliv, ən itʃ ɪz əfɹeɪd tə sɛn faɪɾɪŋ mɛn ɛlswɛɹ. pipəl wɪspɝ ðət ðə wɝld ɪz ɛndɪŋ, ðət ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪz lus əɡɛn. ʃaɪnɝ wɪl ɹaɪd tə tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp əloʊn, ən wɪl bi aʊtnʌmbɝɾ ət lis tɛn tə wʌn. ət list. ɪt meɪ bi ðə læst ɪnɡɑðɝɪŋ ə ðə lænsɪz.

"Kandor, Arafel, Saldaea - the Trollocs raided them all straight through the winter. Nothing like that has happened since the Trolloc Wars; the raids have never been so fierce, or so large, or pressed home so hard. Every king and council is sure a great thrust is coming out of the Blight, and every one of the Borderlands believes it is coming at them. None of their scouts, and none of the Warders, report Trolloc massing above their borders, as we have here, but they believe, and each is afraid to send fighting men elsewhere. People whisper that the world is ending, that the Dark One is loose again. Shienar will ride to Tarwin's Gap alone, and we will be outnumbered at least ten to one. At least. It may be the last Ingathering of the Lances.

"læn - noʊ! - daɪ ʃæn, fəɹ jə ɑɹ ə daɪəɾɪmd bæɾəl lɔɹɾ ə mɔlkiɝ wʌtɛvɝ jə seɪ. daɪ ʃæn, ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn bænɝ ɪn ðə væn wəd pʊt hɑɹɾ ɪndə mɛn u noʊ ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹaɪɾɪŋ nɔɹθ tə daɪ. ðə wɝd wɪl spɹɛd laɪk waɪldfaɪɝ, ən ðoʊ ðɛɹ kɪŋz əv toʊld əm tə hoʊld wɛɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ, lænsɪz wɪl kʌm fɹəm ɝæfəl ən kændɝ, ən ivən fɹəm sɑldɑiə. ðoʊ ðeɪ kænɑt kʌm ɪn taɪm tə stænd wɪð əs ɪn ðə ɡæp, ðeɪ meɪ seɪv ʃaɪnɝ."

"Lan - no! - Dai Shan, for you are a Diademed Battle Lord of Malkier Whatever you say. Dai Shan, the Golden Crane banner in the van would put heart into men who know they are riding north to die. The word will spread like wildfire, and though their kings have told them to hold where they are, lances will come from Arafel and Kandor, and even from Saldaea. Though they cannot come in time to stand with us in the Gap, they may save Shienar."

læn pɪɹɾ ɪndə hɪz waɪn. hɪz feɪs dɪd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ, bʌt waɪn slɑpt oʊvɝ ɪz hænd; ðə sɪlvɝ ɡɑblət kɹʌmpəld ɪn ɪz ɡɹɪp. ə sɝvən tʊk ðə ɹuən kʌp ən waɪp ðə wɔɹɾɝz hænd wɪð ə klɔθ; ə sɛkən pʊɾ ə fɹɛʃ ɡɑbləɾ ɪn ɪz hænd waɪl ði ʌðɝ wɑz wɪskt əweɪ. læn dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs. "aɪ kænɑt!" hi wɪspɝd hɔɹsli. wən i ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛɾ ɪz blu aɪz bɝnd wɪð ə fɪɹs laɪt, bʌɾ ɪz vɔɪs wɑz kɑm əɡɛn, ən flæt. "aɪ æm ə wɔɹɾɝ, eɪɡəlmɝ." hɪz ʃɑɹp ɡeɪz slɪɾ əkɹɔs ɹænd ən mæt ən pɛɹɪn tə mɔɪɹeɪn. "æt fɝs laɪɾ aɪ ɹaɪd tə ðə blaɪt."

Lan peered into his wine. His face did not change, but wine slopped over his hand; the silver goblet crumpled in his grip. A servant took the ruined cup and wiped the Warder's hand with a cloth; a second put a fresh goblet in his hand while the other was whisked away. Lan did not seem to notice. "I cannot!" he whispered hoarsely. When he raised his head his blue eyes burned with a fierce light, but his voice was calm again, and flat. "I am a Warder, Agelmar." His sharp gaze slid across Rand and Mat and Perrin to Moiraine. "At first light I ride to the Blight."

eɪɡəlmɝ saɪd hɛvəli. "mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ, wɪl jə nɑt kʌm, ət list? ən ɛɛs sədaɪ kəd meɪk ðə dɪfɝəns."

Agelmar sighed heavily. "Moiraine Sedai, will you not come, at least? An Aes Sedai could make the difference."

"aɪ kænɑt, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ." mɔɪɹeɪn sim tʃɹʌbəld. "ðɛɹ ɪz ɪndiɾ ə bæɾəl tə bi fɔt, ən ɪts nɑt tʃæns ðət ðə tʃɹɑləks ɡæðɝ əbʌv ʃaɪnɝ, bʌɾ əɹ bæɾəl, ðə tʃɹu bæɾəl wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn, wɪl teɪk pleɪs ɪn ðə blaɪt, ət ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld. jə mʌs faɪt jəɹ bæɾəl, ən wi aʊɝz."

"I cannot, Lord Agelmar." Moiraine seemed troubled. "There is indeed a battle to be fought, and it is not chance that the Trollocs gather above Shienar, but our battle, the true battle with the Dark One, will take place in the Blight, at the Eye of the World. You must fight your battle, and we ours."

"ju kænɑt bi seɪɪŋ hiz lus!" ɹɑklaɪk eɪɡəlmɝ saʊndəd ʃeɪkən, ən mɔɪɹeɪn kwɪkli ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

"You cannot be saying he is loose!" Rocklike Agelmar sounded shaken, and Moiraine quickly shook her head.

"nɑt jɛt. ɪf wi wɪn ət ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld, pɝhæps nɑɾ ɛvɝ əɡɛn."

"Not yet. If we win at the Eye of the World, perhaps not ever again."

"kæn jə ivən faɪn ði aɪ, ɛɛs sədaɪ? ɪf hoʊldɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn dɪpɛnz ɑn ðæt, wi maɪɾ əz wɛl bi dɛd. mɛni hæv tʃɹaɪɾ ən feɪld."

"Can you even find the Eye, Aes Sedai? If holding the Dark One depends on that, we might as well be dead. Many have tried and failed."

"aɪ kən faɪn ɪt, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ. hoʊp ɪz nɑt lɔs jɛt."

"I can find it, Lord Agelmar. Hope is not lost yet."

eɪɡəlmɝ stʌɾid hɝ, ən ðən ði ʌðɝz. hi əpɪɹd pʌzəl baɪ nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin; ðɛɹ fɑɹmkloʊðz kəntʃɹæstəd ʃɑɹpli wɪð mɔɪɹeɪnz sɪlk dʒɹɛs, ðoʊ ɔl wɝ tʃɹævəl-steɪnd. "ðeɪ ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, tu?" hi æsk daʊtfəli. wən mɔɪɹeɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, hi simd ivən mɔɹ kənfjuzd. hɪz ɡeɪz ɹæn oʊvɝ ðə jʌŋ mɛn fɹəm ɛmənz fild, sɛɾəlɪŋ ɑn ɹænd, bɹʌʃɪŋ ðə ɹɛd-ɹæp sɔɹɾ əɾ ɪz weɪst. "ə stʃɹeɪnʒ ɡɑɹd jə teɪk wɪð ju, ɛɛs sədaɪ. oʊnli wʌn faɪɾɪŋ mæn." hi ɡlænst ət pɛɹɪn, ən ət ði æks hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ɪz bɛlt. "pɝhæps tu. bʌt boʊθ bɛɹli mɔɹ ðən lædz. lemi sɛn mɛn wɪð ju. ə hʌnʒɹəd lænsɪz mɔɹ əɹ lɛs wɪl meɪk noʊ dɪfɝəns ɪn ðə ɡæp, bʌt jəl nid mɔɹ ðən wʌn wɔɹɾɝ ən θɹi juðz. ən tu wɪmən wɪl nɑt hɛlp, ənlɛs ðeɪ ɑɹ il ɪn dɪsɡaɪz. ðə blaɪɾ ɪz wɝs ðən juʒəwəl ðɪs jɪɹ. ɪt - stɝz."

Agelmar studied her, and then the others. He appeared puzzled by Nynaeve and Egwene; their farmclothes contrasted sharply with Moiraine's silk dress, though all were travel-stained. "They are Aes Sedai, too?" he asked doubtfully. When Moiraine shook her head, he seemed even more confused. His gaze ran over the young men from Emond's Field, settling on Rand, brushing the red-wrapped sword at his waist. "A strange guard you take with you, Aes Sedai. Only one fighting man." He glanced at Perrin, and at the axe hanging from his belt. "Perhaps two. But both barely more than lads. Let me send men with you. A hundred lances more or less will make no difference in the Gap, but you will need more than one Warder and three youths. And two women will not help, unless they are Aiel in disguise. The Blight is worse than usual this year. It - stirs."

"ə hʌnʒɹəd lænsɪz wəd bi tu mɛni," læn sɛd, "æn ə θaʊzənd nɑɾ ɪnʌf. ðə lɑɹdʒɝ ðə pɑɹɾi wi teɪk ɪndə ðə blaɪt, ðə mɔɹ tʃæns wɪl ətʃɹækt ətɛnʃən. wi mʌst ɹitʃ ði aɪ wɪθaʊt faɪɾɪŋ, ɪf wi kæn. jə noʊ ði aʊtkʌm ɪz ɔl bʌt fɔɹtoʊld wən tʃɹɑləks fɔɹs bæɾəl ɪnsaɪd ðə blaɪt."

"A hundred lances would be too many," Lan said, "and a thousand not enough. The larger the party we take into the Blight, the more chance we will attract attention. We must reach the Eye without fighting, if we can. You know the outcome is all but foretold when Trollocs force battle inside the Blight."

eɪɡəlmɝ nɑɾəd ɡɹɪmli, bʌɾ i ɹəfjuz tə ɡɪv ʌp. "fjuɝ, ðɛn. ivən tɛn ɡʊd mɛn wəd ɡɪv jə ə bɛɾɝ tʃæns ʌv ɛskɔɹɾɪŋ mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ ən ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən tə ðə ɡɹin mæn ðən wɪl dʒʌs ðiz jʌŋ fɛloʊz."

Agelmar nodded grimly, but he refused to give up. "Fewer, then. Even ten good men would give you a better chance of escorting Moiraine Sedai and the other two women to the Green Man than will just these young fellows."

ɹænd əbɹʌpli ɹilaɪz ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə əsumd ɪt wɑz nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin u wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn wəd faɪɾ əɡɛns ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ɪt wɑz nætʃɹəl. ðət sɔɹɾ ə stʃɹʌɡəl mɛn juzɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ən ðət mɛnt wɪmən. ðət sɔɹɾ ə stʃɹʌɡəl minz juzɪŋ ðə paʊɝ. hi tʌkt ɪz θʌmz bɪhaɪn ɪz sɔɹd bɛlt ən ɡɹɪp ðə bʌkəl hɑɹd tə kip ɪz hænz fɹəm ʃeɪkɪŋ.

Rand abruptly realized the Lord of Fal Dara assumed it was Nynaeve and Egwene who with Moiraine would fight against the Dark One. It was natural. That sort of struggle meant using the One Power, and that meant women. That sort of struggle means using the Power. He tucked his thumbs behind his sword belt and gripped the buckle hard to keep his hands from shaking.

"noʊ mɛn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. eɪɡəlmɝ oʊpən ɪz maʊθ əɡɛn, ən ʃi wɛn ɑn bɪfɔɹ i kəd spik. "ɪɾ ɪz ðə neɪtʃɝ ə ði aɪ, ən ðə neɪtʃɝ ə ðə ɡɹin mæn. haʊ mɛni fɹəm fæl dæɹə hæv ɛvɝ faʊn ðə ɡɹin mæn ən ði aɪ?"

"No men," Moiraine said. Agelmar opened his mouth again, and she went on before he could speak. "It is the nature of the Eye, and the nature of the Green Man. How many from Fal Dara have ever found the Green Man and the Eye?"

"ɛvɝ?" eɪɡəlmɝ ʃɹʌɡd. "sɪns ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, jə kəd kaʊn əm ɑn ðə fɪŋɡɝz ʌv wʌn hænd. noʊ mɔɹ ðən wʌn ɪn faɪv jɪɹz fɹəm ɔl ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz təɡɛðɝ."

"Ever?" Agelmar shrugged. "Since the War of the Hundred Years, you could count them on the fingers of one hand. No more than one in five years from all the Borderlands together."

"noʊ wʌn faɪnz ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "ənlɛs ðə ɡɹin mæn wɑns əm tə faɪn ɪt. niɾ ɪz ðə ki, ən ɪntɛntʃən. aɪ noʊ wɛɹ tə ɡoʊ - aɪ hæv bɪn ðəɹ bɪfɔɹ." ɹændz hɛd wɪpt ɝaʊn ɪn sɝpɹaɪz; hɪz wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn əmʌŋ ði ɛmənz fildɝz, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs. "bʌt wʌn əmʌŋ əs sikɪŋ ɡlɔɹi, sikɪŋ tə æɾ ɪz neɪm tə ðoʊz fɔɹ, ən wi meɪ nɛvɝ faɪn ɪt ðoʊ aɪ teɪk əs stʃɹeɪt tə ðə spɑɾ aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ."

"No one finds the Eye of the World," Moiraine said, "unless the Green Man wants them to find it. Need is the key, and intention. I know where to go - I have been there before." Rand's head whipped around in surprise; his was not the only one among the Emond's Fielders, but the Aes Sedai did not seem to notice. "But one among us seeking glory, seeking to add his name to those four, and we may never find it though I take us straight to the spot I remember."

"ju hæv sin ðə ɡɹin mæn, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ?" ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə saʊndəɾ ɪmpɹɛst, bʌɾ ɪn ðə nɛks bɹɛθ i fɹaʊnd. "bʌɾ ɪf juv ɔlɹɛɾi mɛɾ ɪm wʌns. . . ."

"You have seen the Green Man, Moiraine Sedai?" The Lord of Fal Dara sounded impressed, but in the next breath he frowned. "But if you have already met him once. . . ."

"niɾ ɪz ðə ki," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd sɔfli, "æn ðəɹ kən bi noʊ ɡɹeɪɾɝ nid ðən maɪn. ðən aʊɝz. ən aɪ hæv sʌmθɪŋ ðoʊz ʌðɝ sikɝz əv nɑt."

"Need is the key," Moiraine said softly, "and there can be no greater need than mine. Than ours. And I have something those other seekers have not."

hɝ aɪz bɛɹli stɝd fɹəm eɪɡəlmɝz feɪs, bʌt ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ ðeɪ hæd dʒɹɪftəd təwɔɹd lɔɪəl, dʒʌs fəɹ ən ɪnstən bɪfɔɹ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pʊld əm bæk. ɹænd mɛt ði oʊɡiɝz aɪz, ən lɔɪəl ʃɹʌɡd.

Her eyes barely stirred from Agelmar's face, but Rand was sure they had drifted toward Loial, just for an instant before the Aes Sedai pulled them back. Rand met the Ogier's eyes, and Loial shrugged.

"tɑvɝən," ði oʊɡiɝ sɛd sɔfli.

"Ta'veren," the Ogier said softly.

eɪɡəlmɝ θɹu ʌp ɪz hænz. "ɪt wɪl bi əz jə seɪ, ɛɛs sədaɪ. pis, ɪf ðə ɹil bæɾəl ɪz tə bi ət ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld, aɪm tɛmptəd tə teɪk ðə blæk hɔk bænɝ æftɝ jə ɪnstɛɾ ə tə ðə ɡæp. aɪ kəd kʌɾ ə pæθ fəɹ jə - "

Agelmar threw up his hands. "It will be as you say, Aes Sedai. Peace, if the real battle is to be at the Eye of the World, I am tempted to take the Black Hawk banner after you instead of to the Gap. I could cut a path for you - "

"ðæt wəd bi dɪzæstɝ, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ. boʊθ ət tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp ən ət ði aɪ. juv jəɹ bæɾəl, ən wi aʊɝz."

"That would be disaster, Lord Agelmar. Both at Tarwin's Gap and at the Eye. You have your battle, and we ours."

"pis! əz jə seɪ, ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Peace! As you say, Aes Sedai."

hævɪŋ ɹitʃt ə dɪsɪʒən, haʊɛvɝ mʌtʃ i dɪslaɪkt ɪt, ðə ʃeɪvən-hɛɾəd lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə sim tə pʊɾ ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɪz maɪnd. hi ɪnvaɪɾəd əm tə teɪbəl wɪð hɪm, ɔl ðə waɪl meɪkɪŋ kɑnvɝseɪʃən əbaʊt hɔks ən hɔɹsəz ən dɑɡz, bʌt wɪð nɛvɝ ə mɛnʃən ə tʃɹɑləks, əɹ tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp, əɹ ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld.

Having reached a decision, however much he disliked it, the shaven-headed Lord of Fal Dara seemed to put it out of his mind. He invited them to table with him, all the while making conversation about hawks and horses and dogs, but with never a mention of Trollocs, or Tarwin's Gap, or the Eye of the World.

ðə tʃeɪmbɝ wɛɹ ðeɪ eɪt wɑz əz stɑɹk ən pleɪn əz lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝz stʌɾi hæd bɪn, wɪð lɪɾəl mɔɹ fɝnɪʃɪŋ ɪt ðən ðə teɪbəl ən tʃɛɹz ðɛmsɛlvz, ən ðeɪ wɝ səvɪɹ ɪn laɪn ən fɔɹm. bjuɾəfəl, bʌt səvɪɹ. ə bɪɡ faɪɝpleɪs wɔɹm ðə ɹum, bʌt nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ ðəɾ ə mæn kɔld aʊt hɝidli wəd bi stʌn baɪ ðə koʊld aʊtsaɪd. lɪvɹid sɝvəns bɹɔt sup ən bɹɛɾ ən tʃiz, ən ðə tɔk wɑz ə bʊks ən mjuzɪk əntɪl lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ ɹilaɪz ði ɛmənz fil foʊk wɝ nɑt tɔkɪŋ. laɪk ə ɡʊd hoʊst i æsk dʒɛnli pɹoʊbɪŋ kwɛstʃənz dɪzaɪn tə bɹɪŋ əm aʊɾ ə ðɛɹ kwaɪət.

The chamber where they ate was as stark and plain as Lord Agelmar's study had been, with little more furnishing it than the table and chairs themselves, and they were severe in line and form. Beautiful, but severe. A big fireplace warmed the room, but not so much that a man called out hurriedly would be stunned by the cold outside. Liveried servants brought soup and bread and cheese, and the talk was of books and music until Lord Agelmar realized the Emond's Field folk were not talking. Like a good host he asked gently probing questions designed to bring them out of their quiet.

ɹænd sun faʊn hɪmsɛlf kəmpiɾɪŋ tə tɛl əbaʊɾ ɛmənz fild ən ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ɪt wɑz ən ɛfɝt nɑt tə seɪ tu mʌtʃ. hi hoʊp ði ʌðɝz wɝ ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðɛɹ tʌŋz, mæt ɪspɛʃli. nɪneɪiv əloʊn hɛl hɝsɛlf bæk, iɾɪŋ ən dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ saɪlənli.

Rand soon found himself competing to tell about Emond's Field and the Two Rivers. It was an effort not to say too much. He hoped the others were guarding their tongues, Mat especially. Nynaeve alone held herself back, eating and drinking silently.

"ðɛɹz ə sɔŋ ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz," mæt sɛd. " 'kʌmɪŋ hoʊm fɹəm tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp.' " hi fɪnɪʃt hɛzɪɾəntli, əz ɪf sʌɾənli ɹilaɪzɪŋ ðəɾ i wɑz bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp wʌt ðeɪ hæd bɪn əvɔɪɾɪŋ, bʌɾ eɪɡəlmɝ hændəld ɪt smuðli.

"There's a song in the Two Rivers," Mat said. " 'Coming Home From Tarwin's Gap.' " He finished hesitantly, as if suddenly realizing that he was bringing up what they had been avoiding, but Agelmar handled it smoothly.

"lɪɾəl wʌndɝ. fju lænz əv nɑt sɛn mɛn tə hoʊl bæk ðə blaɪɾ oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz."

"Little wonder. Few lands have not sent men to hold back the Blight over the years."

ɹænd lʊkt ət mæt ən pɛɹɪn. mæt saɪlənli fɔɹm ðə wɝd meɪnɛðɝən.

Rand looked at Mat and Perrin. Mat silently formed the word Manetheren.

eɪɡəlmɝ wɪspɝd tə wʌn ə ðə sɝvəns, ən waɪl ʌðɝz klɪɹd ðə teɪbəl ðət mæn vænɪʃt ən ɹɪtɝnd wɪð ə kænəstɝ, ən kleɪ paɪps fəɹ læn, lɔɪəl, ən lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ. "tu ɹɪvɝz təbæk," ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə sɛɾ əz ðeɪ fɪl ðɛɹ paɪps. "hɑɹd tə kʌm baɪ, hɪɹ, bʌt wɝθ ðə kɑst."

Agelmar whispered to one of the servants, and while others cleared the table that man vanished and returned with a canister, and clay pipes for Lan, Loial, and Lord Agelmar. "Two Rivers tabac," the Lord of Fal Dara said as they filled their pipes. "Hard to come by, here, but worth the cost."

wən lɔɪəl ən ðə tu oʊldɝ mɛn wɝ pʌfɪŋ kəntɛntədli, eɪɡəlmɝ ɡlænst ət ði oʊɡiɝ. "ju sim tʃɹʌbəld, bɪldɝ. nɑt bɪsɛt baɪ ðə lɔŋɪŋ, aɪ hoʊp. haʊ lɔŋ əv jə bɪn əweɪ fɹəm ðə stɛɾɪŋ?"

When Loial and the two older men were puffing contentedly, Agelmar glanced at the Ogier. "You seem troubled, Builder. Not beset by the Longing, I hope. How long have you been away from the stedding?"

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑt ðə lɔŋɪŋ; aɪ hæv nɑt bɪn ɡɔn sətʃ ə taɪm əz ðæt." lɔɪəl ʃɹʌɡd, ən ðə blu-ɡɹeɪ stʃɹimɝ ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ɪz paɪp meɪɾ ə spaɪɹəl əbʌv ðə teɪbəl əz i dʒɛstʃɝd. "aɪ ɪkspɛktəd - hoʊpt - ðət ðə ɡɹoʊv wəd stɪl bi hɪɹ. səm ɹɛmnən ə mæfəl dɑɾɝɑnɛl, ət list."

"It is not the Longing; I have not been gone such a time as that." Loial shrugged, and the blue-gray streamer rising from his pipe made a spiral above the table as he gestured. "I expected - hoped - that the grove would still be here. Some remnant of Mafal Dadaranell, at least."

"kaɪsɝi ti wɑnʃoʊ," eɪɡəlmɝ mɝmɝd. "ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz lɛf nʌθɪŋ bʌt mɛmɹiz, lɔɪəl, sʌn ʌv ɑɹənt, ən pipəl tə bɪld ɑn ðɛm. ðeɪ kəd nɑt dupləkeɪt ðə bɪldɝz' wɝk, ɛni mɔɹ ðən kəɾ aɪ. ðoʊz ɪntʃɹəkət kɝvz ən pæɾɝnz jəɹ pipəl kɹieɪɾ ɑɹ bɪɑn hjumən aɪz ən hænz tə meɪk. pɝhæps wi wɪʃt tə əvɔɪɾ ə pʊɹ ɪməteɪʃən ðət wəɾ oʊnli hæv bɪn ən ɛvɝ-pɹɛzən ɹimaɪndɝ tə əs ʌv wʌt wi hæd lɔst. ðəɹ ɪz ə dɪfɹən bjuɾi ɪn sɪmplɪsəɾi, ɪn ə sɪŋɡəl laɪn pleɪs dʒʌst soʊ, ə sɪŋɡəl flaʊɝ əmʌŋ ðə ɹɑks. ðə hɑɹʃnəs ə ðə stoʊn meɪks ðə flaʊɝ mɔɹ pɹɛʃəs. wi tʃɹaɪ nɑt tə dwɛl tu mʌtʃ ɑn wʌɾ ɪz ɡɔn. ðə stʃɹɔŋɡəs hɑɹt wɪl bɹeɪk ʌndɝ ðət stʃɹeɪn."

"Kiserai ti Wansho," Agelmar murmured. "The Trolloc Wars left nothing but memories, Loial, son of Arent, and people to build on them. They could not duplicate the Builders' work, any more than could I. Those intricate curves and patterns your people create are beyond human eyes and hands to make. Perhaps we wished to avoid a poor imitation that would only have been an ever-present reminder to us of what we had lost. There is a different beauty in simplicity, in a single line placed just so, a single flower among the rocks. The harshness of the stone makes the flower more precious. We try not to dwell too much on what is gone. The strongest heart will break under that strain."

"ðə ɹoʊz pɛɾəl floʊts ɑn wɔɾɝ," læn ɹəsaɪɾəd sɔfli. "ðə kɪŋfɪʃɝ flæʃɪz əbʌv ðə pɑnd. laɪf ən bjuɾi swɝl ɪn ðə mɪdst ə dɛθ."

"The rose petal floats on water," Lan recited softly. "The kingfisher flashes above the pond. Life and beauty swirl in the midst of death."

"jɛs," eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd. "jɛs. ðət wʌn əz ɔlweɪz sɪmbəlaɪz ðə hoʊl ʌv ɪt tə mi, tu." ðə tu mɛn baʊd ðɛɹ hɛdz tə wʌn ənʌðɝ.

"Yes," Agelmar said. "Yes. That one has always symbolized the whole of it to me, too." The two men bowed their heads to one another.

poʊətʃɹi aʊɾ ə læn? ðə mæn wɑz laɪk ən ʌnjən; ɛvɹi taɪm ɹænd θɔɾ i nu sʌmθɪŋ əbaʊt ðə wɔɹɾɝ, hi dɪskʌvɝɾ ənʌðɝ leɪɝ ʌndɝniθ.

Poetry out of Lan? The man was like an onion; every time Rand thought he knew something about the Warder, he discovered another layer underneath.

lɔɪəl nɑɾəd sloʊli. "pɝhæps aɪ ɔlsoʊ dwɛl tu mʌtʃ ɑn wʌɾ ɪz ɡɔn. ən jɛt, ðə ɡɹoʊvz wɝ bjuɾəfəl." bʌɾ i wɑz lʊkɪŋ ət ðə stɑɹk ɹum əz ɪf siɪŋ ɪɾ ənu, ən sʌɾənli faɪndɪŋ θɪŋz wɝθ siɪŋ.

Loial nodded slowly. "Perhaps I also dwell too much on what is gone. And yet, the groves were beautiful." But he was looking at the stark room as if seeing it anew, and suddenly finding things worth seeing.

ɪŋtʃɹ əpɪɹɾ ən baʊd tə lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ. "jɔɹ pɑɹɾən, lɔɹd, bʌt jə wɑntəd tə noʊ ʌv ɛniθɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi, haʊɛvɝ smɔl."

Ingtar appeared and bowed to Lord Agelmar. "Your pardon, Lord, but you wanted to know of anything out of the ordinary, however small."

"jɛs, wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?"

"Yes, what is it?"

"ə smɔl θɪŋ, lɔɹd. ə stʃɹeɪnʒɝ tʃɹaɪd tə ɛntɝ ðə taʊn. nɑɾ ə ʃaɪnɝ. baɪ hɪz æksɛnt, ə luɡɑɝɾɝ. səmtaɪmz, ət list. wən ðə saʊθ ɡeɪt ɡɑɹdz ətɛmptəd tə kwɛstʃən hɪm, hi ɹæn əweɪ. hi wɑz sin tə ɛntɝ ðə fɔɹəst, bʌɾ oʊnli ə ʃɔɹt taɪm leɪɾɝ i wɑz faʊn skeɪlɪŋ ðə wɔl."

"A small thing, Lord. A stranger tried to enter the town. Not of Shienar. By his accent, a Lugarder. Sometimes, at least. When the South Gate guards attempted to question him, he ran away. He was seen to enter the forest, but only a short time later he was found scaling the wall."

"ə smɔl θɪŋ!" eɪɡəlmɝz tʃɛɹ skɹeɪpt əkɹɔs ðə flɔɹ əz i stʊd. "pis! ðə taʊɝ wɑtʃ ɪz soʊ nɛɡlədʒən ə mæn kən ɹitʃ ðə wɔlz ənsin, ən jə kɔl ɪɾ ə smɔl θɪŋ?"

"A small thing!" Agelmar's chair scraped across the floor as he stood. "Peace! The tower watch is so negligent a man can reach the walls unseen, and you call it a small thing?"

"hi ɪz ə mædmæn, lɔɹd." ɑ tʌtʃt ɪŋtʃɹz vɔɪs. "ðə laɪt ʃilz mædmən. pɝhæps ðə laɪt kloʊk ðə taʊɝ wɑtʃəz aɪz ən əlaʊɾ ɪm tə ɹitʃ ðə wɔlz. ʃʊɹli wʌn pʊɹ mædmæn kən də noʊ hɑɹm."

"He is a madman, Lord." Awe touched Ingtar's voice. "The Light shields madmen. Perhaps the Light cloaked the tower watch's eyes and allowed him to reach the walls. Surely one poor madman can do no harm."

"hæz i bɪn bɹɔt tə ðə kip jɛt? ɡʊd. bɹɪŋ ɪm tə mi hɪɹ. naʊ." ɪŋtʃɹ baʊɾ ən lɛft, ən eɪɡəlmɝ tɝn tə mɔɪɹeɪn. "jɔɹ pɑɹɾən, ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ aɪ mʌst si tə ðɪs. pɝhæps hiz oʊnli ə pɪɾəfəl ɹɛtʃ wɪð ɪz maɪn blaɪndɪd baɪ ðə laɪt, bʌt. . . . tu deɪz ɡɔn, faɪv ʌv əɹ oʊn pipəl wɝ faʊn ɪn ðə naɪt tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə sɔ θɹu ðə hɪnʒɪz ʌv ə hɔɹs-ɡeɪt. smɔl, bʌɾ ɪnʌf tə lɛt tʃɹɑləks ɪn." hi ɡɹɪməst. "dɑɹkfɹɛnz, aɪ səpoʊz, ðoʊ aɪ heɪt tə θɪŋk ɪɾ ʌv ɛni ʃaɪnɝən. ðeɪ wɝ tɔɹn tə pisəz baɪ ðə pipəl bɪfɔɹ ðə ɡɑɹdz kəd teɪk ðɛm, soʊ əl nɛvɝ noʊ. ɪf ʃaɪnɝənz kən bi dɑɹkfɹɛnz, aɪ mʌs bi ɪspɛʃli kɛɹfəl ʌv aʊtləndɝz ɪn ðiz deɪz. ɪf jə wɪʃ tə wɪðdʒɹɔ, əl əv jə ʃoʊn tə jəɹ ɹumz."

"Has he been brought to the keep yet? Good. Bring him to me here. Now." Ingtar bowed and left, and Agelmar turned to Moiraine. "Your pardon, Aes Sedai, but I must see to this. Perhaps he is only a pitiful wretch with his mind blinded by the Light, but. . . . Two days gone, five of our own people were found in the night trying to saw through the hinges of a horse-gate. Small, but enough to let Trollocs in." He grimaced. "Darkfriends, I suppose, though I hate to think it of any Shienaran. They were torn to pieces by the people before the guards could take them, so I'll never know. If Shienarans can be Darkfriends, I must be especially careful of outlanders in these days. If you wish to withdraw, I will have you shown to your rooms."

"dɑɹkfɹɛnz noʊ niðɝ bɔɹɾɝ nɔɹ blʌd," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ ɑɹ faʊn ɪn ɛvɹi lænd, ən ɑɹ ə nʌn. aɪ, tu, æm ɪntʃɹəstəɾ ɪn siɪŋ ðɪs mæn. ðə pæɾɝn ɪz fɔɹmɪŋ ə wɛb, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ, bʌt ðə faɪnəl ʃeɪp ə ðə wɛb ɪz nɑt jɛt sɛt. ɪt meɪ jɛɾ ɛntæŋɡəl ðə wɝld, əɹ ənɹævəl ən sɛt ðə wil tə ə nu wivɪŋ. ət ðɪs pɔɪnt, ivən smɔl θɪŋz kən tʃeɪnʒ ðə ʃeɪp ə ðə wɛb. ət ðɪs pɔɪn aɪm wɛɹi ʌv smɔl θɪŋz aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi."

"Darkfriends know neither border nor blood," Moiraine said. "They are found in every land, and are of none. I, too, am interested in seeing this man. The Pattern is forming a Web, Lord Agelmar, but the final shape of the Web is not yet set. It may yet entangle the world, or unravel and set the Wheel to a new weaving. At this point, even small things can change the shape of the Web. At this point I am wary of small things out of the ordinary."

eɪɡəlmɝ ɡlænst ət nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin. "æz jə wɪʃ, ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Agelmar glanced at Nynaeve and Egwene. "As you wish, Aes Sedai."

ɪŋtʃɹ ɹɪtɝnd, wɪð tu ɡɑɹdz kæɹiɪŋ lɔŋ bɪlz, ən ɛskɔɹɾɪŋ ə mæn u lʊk laɪk ə ɹæɡbæɡ tɝn ɪnsaɪɾ aʊt. ɡɹaɪm leɪɝɾ ɪz feɪs ən mæɾɪd ɪz skɹæɡli, ʌnkʌt hɛɹ ən bɪɹd. hi hʌntʃt ɪndə ðə ɹum, sʌŋkən aɪz dɑɹɾɪŋ ðɪs weɪ ən ðæt. ə ɹænsɪd smɛl wɑftɪɾ əhɛɾ ə hɪm.

Ingtar returned, with two guards carrying long bills, and escorting a man who looked like a ragbag turned inside out. Grime layered his face and matted his scraggly, uncut hair and beard. He hunched into the room, sunken eyes darting this way and that. A rancid smell wafted ahead of him.

ɹænd sæt fɔɹwɝɾ ɪntɛnli, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə si θɹu ɔl ðə dɝt.

Rand sat forward intently, trying to see through all the dirt.

"juv noʊ kɑz tə bi hoʊldɪŋ mi laɪk ðɪs," ðə fɪlθi mæn waɪnd. "aɪm oʊnli ə pʊɹ dɛstətut, əbændən baɪ ðə laɪɾ ən sikɪŋ ə pleɪs, laɪk ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls, tə ʃɛltɝ fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊ."

"You've no cause to be holding me like this," the filthy man whined. "I'm only a poor destitute, abandoned by the Light and seeking a place, like everyone else, to shelter from the Shadow."

"ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz ɑɹ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ pleɪs tə sik - " eɪɡəlmɝ bɪɡæn, wən mæt kʌɾ ɪm ɔf.

"The Borderlands are a strange place to seek - " Agelmar began, when Mat cut him off.

"ðə pɛdlɝ!"

"The peddler!"

"pdən feɪn," pɛɹɪn əɡɹid, nɑɾɪŋ.

"Padan Fain," Perrin agreed, nodding.

"ðə bɛɡɝ," ɹænd sɛd, sʌɾənli hɔɹs. hi sæt bæk ət ðə sʌɾən heɪtʃɹəd ðət flɛɹɾ ɪn feɪnz aɪz. "hiz ðə mæn u wɑz æskɪŋ əbaʊɾ əs ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. hiz tə bi."

"The beggar," Rand said, suddenly hoarse. He sat back at the sudden hatred that flared in Fain's eyes. "He's the man who was asking about us in Caemlyn. He has to be."

"soʊ ðɪs kənsɝnz jə æftɝ ɔl, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ," eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd sloʊli.

"So this concerns you after all, Moiraine Sedai," Agelmar said slowly.

mɔɪɹeɪn nɑɾəd. "aɪ ɡɹeɪtli fɪɹ ðəɾ ɪt dʌz."

Moiraine nodded. "I greatly fear that it does."

"aɪ dɪdnt wɑn tə." feɪn bɪɡæn tə kɹaɪ. fæt tɪɹz kʌt ɹʌnəlz ɪn ðə dɝɾ ɑn ɪz tʃiks, bʌt ðeɪ wɝ əneɪbəl tə ɹitʃ ðə bɑɾəm leɪɝ. "hi meɪd mi! hɪm ən ɪz bɝnɪŋ aɪz." ɹænd flɪntʃt. mæt hæɾ ɪz hæn ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt, noʊ daʊt klʌtʃɪŋ ðə dæɡɝ fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ əɡɛn. "hi meɪd mi hɪz haʊnd! hɪz haʊnd, tə hʌn ən fɑloʊ wɪð nɛvɝ ə bɪɾ ə ɹɛst. oʊnli hɪz haʊnd, ivən æftɝ i θɹu mi əweɪ."

"I didn't want to." Fain began to cry. Fat tears cut runnels in the dirt on his cheeks, but they were unable to reach the bottom layer. "He made me! Him and his burning eyes." Rand flinched. Mat had his hand under his coat, no doubt clutching the dagger from Shadar Logoth again. "He made me his hound! His hound, to hunt and follow with never a bit of rest. Only his hound, even after he threw me away."

"ɪt dʌz kənsɝn əs ɔl," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd ɡɹɪmli. "ɪz ðəɹ ə pleɪs wɛɹ aɪ kən tɔk wɪð ɪm əloʊn, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ?" hɝ maʊθ taɪɾənd wɪð dɪsteɪst. "ænd wɑʃ ɪm fɝst. aɪ meɪ nid tə tʌtʃ hɪm." eɪɡəlmɝ nɑɾəd ən spoʊk sɔfli tə ɪŋtʃɹ, hu baʊɾ ən dɪsəpɪɹd θɹu ðə dɔɹ.

"It does concern us all," Moiraine said grimly. "Is there a place where I can talk with him alone, Lord Agelmar?" Her mouth tightened with distaste. "And wash him first. I may need to touch him." Agelmar nodded and spoke softly to Ingtar, who bowed and disappeared through the door.

"aɪ wɪl nɑt bi kəmpɛld!" ðə vɔɪs wɑz feɪnz, bʌɾ i wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ kɹaɪɪŋ, ən ən ɛɹəɡən snæp hæd ɹipleɪs ðə waɪn. hi stʊɾ əpɹaɪt, nɑt kɹaʊtʃɪŋ əɾ ɔl. θɹoʊɪŋ bæk ɪz hɛd, hi ʃaʊɾəd ət ðə silɪŋ. "nɛvɝ əɡɛn! aɪ - wɪl - nɑt!" hi feɪst eɪɡəlmɝ əz ɪf ðə mɛn flæŋkɪŋ ɪm wɝ ɪz oʊn bɑɾiɡɑɹd ən ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə hɪz ikwəl ɹæðɝ ðən ɪz kæptɝ. hɪz toʊn bɪkeɪm slik ən ɔɪli. "ðɛɹ ɪz ə mɪsəndɝstændɪŋ hɪɹ, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. aɪm səmtaɪmz teɪkən baɪ spɛlz, bʌt ðət wɪl pæs sun. jɛs, sun əl bi ɹɪɾ ə ðɛm." kəntɛmptʃwəsli hi flɪkt ɪz fɪŋɡɝz əɡɛns ðə ɹæɡz i wɔɹ. "du nɑt bi mɪslɛd baɪ ðiz, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. aɪ hæv hæd tə dɪsɡaɪz maɪsɛlf əɡɛns ðoʊz u hæv tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp mi, ən maɪ dʒɝni hæz bɪn lɔŋ ən hɑɹd. bʌɾ ət læst aɪ hæv ɹitʃt lænz wɛɹ mɛn stɪl noʊ ðə deɪnʒɝz ə bælzəmən, wɛɹ mɛn stɪl faɪt ðə dɑɹk wʌn."

"I will not be compelled!" The voice was Fain's, but he was no longer crying, and an arrogant snap had replaced the whine. He stood upright, not crouching at all. Throwing back his head, he shouted at the ceiling. "Never again! I - will - not!" He faced Agelmar as if the men flanking him were his own bodyguard and the Lord of Fal Dara his equal rather than his captor. His tone became sleek and oily. "There is a misunderstanding here, Great Lord. I am sometimes taken by spells, but that will pass soon. Yes, soon I will be rid of them." Contemptuously he flicked his fingers against the rags he wore. "Do not be misled by these, Great Lord. I have had to disguise myself against those who have tried to stop me, and my journey has been long and hard. But at last I have reached lands where men still know the dangers of Ba'alzamon, where men still fight the Dark One."

ɹænd stɛɹd, ɡɑəlɪŋ. ɪt wɑz feɪnz vɔɪs, bʌt ðə wɝdz dɪd nɑt saʊn laɪk ðə pɛdlɝ əɾ ɔl.

Rand stared, goggling. It was Fain's voice, but the words did not sound like the peddler at all.

"soʊ juv kʌm hɪɹ kəz wi faɪt tʃɹɑləks," eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd. "æn jə ɑɹ soʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðət sʌmwʌn wɑns tə stɑp ju. ðiz pipəl seɪ jə ɑɹ ə pɛdlɝ kɔl pdən feɪn, ən ðət jə ɑɹ fɑloʊɪŋ ðɛm."

"So you've come here because we fight Trollocs," Agelmar said. "And you are so important that someone wants to stop you. These people say you are a peddler called Padan Fain, and that you are following them."

feɪn hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. hi ɡlænst ət mɔɪɹeɪn ən hɝidli pʊld ɪz aɪz əweɪ fɹəm ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. hɪz ɡeɪz ɹæn əkɹɔs ði ɛmənz fildɝz, ðən dʒɝk bæk tə eɪɡəlmɝ. ɹænd fɛl ðə heɪɾ ɪn ðət lʊk, ən ðə fɪɹ. wən feɪn spoʊk əɡɛn, ðoʊ, hɪz vɔɪs wɑz ənɹʌfəld. "pdən feɪn ɪz sɪmpli wʌn ə ðə mɛni dɪsɡaɪzɪz aɪ hæv bɪn fɔɹs tə wɛɹ oʊvɝ ðə jɪɹz. fɹɛnz ə ðə dɑɹk pɝsu mi, fəɹ aɪ hæv lɝn haʊ tə dɪfit ðə ʃædoʊ. aɪ kən ʃoʊ jə haʊ tə dɪfit hɪm, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd."

Fain hesitated. He glanced at Moiraine and hurriedly pulled his eyes away from the Aes Sedai. His gaze ran across the Emond's Fielders, then jerked back to Agelmar. Rand felt the hate in that look, and the fear. When Fain spoke again, though, his voice was unruffled. "Padan Fain is simply one of the many disguises I have been forced to wear over the years. Friends of the Dark pursue me, for I have learned how to defeat the Shadow. I can show you how to defeat him, Great Lord."

"wi də əz wɛl əz mɛn kæn," eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd dʒɹaɪli. "ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz, bʌt wɪv fɔt ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɔlmoʊst sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld wɪθaʊt pɛdlɝz tə titʃ əs haʊ."

"We do as well as men can," Agelmar said dryly. "The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills, but we have fought the Dark One almost since the Breaking of the World without peddlers to teach us how."

"ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, jəɹ maɪɾ ɪz ənkwɛstʃənd, bʌt kən ɪt stæn əɡɛns ðə dɑɹk wʌn fɝɛvɝ? dʒju nɑɾ ɔfən faɪn jɝsɛlf pɹɛs tə hoʊld? fɝɡɪv maɪ təmɛɹəɾi, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd; hɪl kɹʌʃ jə ɪn ði ɛnd, əz jə ɑɹ. aɪ noʊ; bɪliv mi, aɪ du. bʌɾ aɪ kən ʃoʊ jə haʊ tə skaʊɝ ðə ʃædoʊ fɹəm ðə lænd, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd." hɪz toʊn bɪkeɪm ivən mɔɹ ʌŋtʃwəs, ðoʊ stɪl hɔɾi. "ɪf jə bʌt tʃɹaɪ wʌɾ aɪ ædvaɪz, jəl si, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. jəl klɛnz ðə lænd. ju, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, kən də ɪt, ɪf jə dɝɛk jəɹ maɪɾ ɪn ðə ɹaɪt dɝɛkʃən. əvɔɪd lɛɾɪŋ tɑɹ vəlɑn ɛntæŋɡəl jə ɪn ɪts snɛɹz, ən jə kən seɪv ðə wɝld. ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, jəl bi ðə mæn ɹɪmɛmbɝd θɹu hɪstɝi fəɹ bɹɪŋɪŋ faɪnəl vɪktɝi tə ðə laɪt." ðə ɡɑɹdz hɛl ðɛɹ pleɪsəz, bʌt ðɛɹ hænz ʃɪftəɾ ɑn ðə lɔŋ ʃæfs ə ðə bɪlz əz ɪf ðeɪ θɔt ðeɪ maɪɾ əv tə juz ðɛm.

"Great Lord, your might is unquestioned, but can it stand against the Dark One forever? Do you not often find yourself pressed to hold? Forgive my temerity, Great Lord; he will crush you in the end, as you are. I know; believe me, I do. But I can show you how to scour the Shadow from the land, Great Lord." His tone became even more unctuous, though still haughty. "If you but try what I advise, you will see, Great Lord. You will cleanse the land. You, Great Lord, can do it, if you direct your might in the right direction. Avoid letting Tar Valon entangle you in its snares, and you can save the world. Great Lord, you will be the man remembered through history for bringing final victory to the Light." The guards held their places, but their hands shifted on the long shafts of the bills as if they thought they might have to use them.

"hi θɪŋks ə ɡɹeɪt dil ə hɪmsɛlf fəɹ ə pɛdlɝ," eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd tə læn oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "aɪ θɪŋk ɪŋtʃɹ ɪz ɹaɪt. hiz mæd."

"He thinks a great deal of himself for a peddler," Agelmar said to Lan over his shoulder. "I think Ingtar is right. He is mad."

feɪnz aɪz taɪɾənd æŋɡɹəli, bʌɾ ɪz vɔɪs ɹɪmeɪn smuð. "ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, aɪ noʊ maɪ wɝdz mʌst əpɪɹ ɡɹændioʊs, bʌɾ ɪf jəl oʊnli - " hi kʌɾ ɔf əbɹʌpli, stɛpɪŋ bæk, əz mɔɪɹeɪn ɹoʊz ən stɑɹɾəd sloʊli ɝaʊn ðə teɪbəl. oʊnli ðə ɡɑɹdz' loʊɝd bɪlz kɛp feɪn fɹəm bækɪŋ ɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ə ðə ɹum.

Fain's eyes tightened angrily, but his voice remained smooth. "Great Lord, I know my words must appear grandiose, but if you will only - " He cut off abruptly, stepping back, as Moiraine rose and started slowly around the table. Only the guards' lowered bills kept Fain from backing right out of the room.

stɑpɪŋ bɪhaɪn mæts tʃɛɹ, mɔɪɹeɪn pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ən bɛn tə wɪspɝ ɪn ɪz ɪɹ. wʌtɛvɝ ʃi sɛd, ðə tɛnʃən wɛn aʊɾ ə hɪz feɪs, ən i tʊk ɪz hæn fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz koʊt. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛn ɑn əntɪl ʃi stʊd bɪsaɪɾ eɪɡəlmɝ, kənfɹʌntɪŋ feɪn. əz ʃi keɪm tə ə hɔlt, ðə pɛdlɝ sæŋk ɪndə ə kɹaʊtʃ wʌns mɔɹ.

Stopping behind Mat's chair, Moiraine put a hand on his shoulder and bent to whisper in his ear. Whatever she said, the tension went out of his face, and he took his hand from under his coat. The Aes Sedai went on until she stood beside Agelmar, confronting Fain. As she came to a halt, the peddler sank into a crouch once more.

"aɪ heɪt hɪm," hi wɪmpɝd. "aɪ wɑnə bi fɹi ʌv hɪm. aɪ wɑnə wɔk ɪn ðə laɪɾ əɡɛn." hɪz ʃoʊldɝz bɪɡæn tə ʃeɪk, ən tɪɹz stʃɹim daʊn ɪz feɪs ivən mɔɹ hɛvəli ðən bɪfɔɹ. "hi meɪd mi də ɪt."

"I hate him," he whimpered. "I want to be free of him. I want to walk in the Light again." His shoulders began to shake, and tears streamed down his face even more heavily than before. "He made me do it."

"aɪ æm əfɹeɪd hiz mɔɹ ðən ə pɛdlɝ, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "lɛs ðən hjumən, wɝs ðən vaɪl, mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən jə kən ɪmædʒən. hi kən bi beɪðd æftɝ aɪ hæv spoʊkən wɪð hɪm. aɪ dɛɹ nɑt weɪst ə mɪnət. kʌm, læn."

"I am afraid he is more than a peddler, Lord Agelmar," Moiraine said. "Less than human, worse than vile, more dangerous than you can imagine. He can be bathed after I have spoken with him. I dare not waste a minute. Come, Lan."


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾisɛvən


CHAPTER 47

mɔɹ teɪlz ə ðə wil


More Tales of the Wheel

ən ɪtʃi ɹɛsləsnəs hæd ɹænd peɪsɪŋ bɪsaɪd ðə daɪnɪŋ teɪbəl. twɛlv stʃɹaɪdz. ðə teɪbəl wɑz ɪɡzækli twɛlv stʃɹaɪdz lɔŋ noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ mɛni taɪmz i stɛpt ɪɾ ɔf. ɪɹɪɾəbli hi meɪd hɪmsɛlf stɑp kipɪŋ tæli. stupəd θɪŋ tə bi duɪŋ. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ haʊ lɔŋ ðə blʌɾi teɪbəl ɪz. ə fju mɪnəts leɪɾɝ i dɪskʌvɝd ðəɾ i wɑz kaʊntɪŋ ðə nʌmbɝ ə tʃɹɪps i meɪɾ ʌp ðə teɪbəl ən bæk. wʌɾ ɪz i seɪɪŋ tə mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn? dʌz i noʊ waɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪz æftɝ ʌs? dʌz i noʊ wɪtʃ ʌv əs ðə dɑɹk wʌn wɑns?

An itchy restlessness had Rand pacing beside the dining table. Twelve strides. The table was exactly twelve strides long no matter how many times he stepped it off. Irritably he made himself stop keeping tally. Stupid thing to be doing. I don't care how long the bloody table is. A few minutes later he discovered that he was counting the number of trips he made up the table and back. What is he saying to Moiraine and Lan? Does he know why the Dark One is after us? Does he know which of us the Dark One wants?

hi ɡlænst əɾ ɪz fɹɛnz. pɛɹɪn hæd kɹʌmbəld ə pis ə bɹɛɾ ən wɑz aɪdli pʊʃɪŋ ðə kɹʌmz ɝaʊn ɑn ðə teɪbəl wɪð wʌn fɪŋɡɝ. hɪz jɛloʊ aɪz stɛɹɾ ənblɪŋkɪŋ ət ðə kɹʌmz, bʌt ðeɪ sim tə si sʌmθɪŋ fɑɹ ɔf. mæt slaʊtʃt ɪn ɪz tʃɛɹ, aɪz hæf kloʊzd ən ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋz ʌv ə ɡɹɪn ɑn ɪz feɪs. ɪt wɑz ə nɝvəs ɡɹɪn, nɑɾ əmjuzmənt. aʊtwɝdli hi lʊk laɪk ði oʊl mæt, bʌt fɹəm taɪm tə taɪm i ʌnkɑnʃəsli tʌtʃt ðə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ dæɡɝ θɹu hɪz koʊt. wʌɾ ɪz feɪn tɛlɪŋ hɝ? wʌt dʌz i noʊ?

He glanced at his friends. Perrin had crumbled a piece of bread and was idly pushing the crumbs around on the table with one finger. His yellow eyes stared unblinking at the crumbs, but they seemed to see something far off. Mat slouched in his chair, eyes half closed and the beginnings of a grin on his face. It was a nervous grin, not amusement. Outwardly he looked like the old Mat, but from time to time he unconsciously touched the Shadar Logoth dagger through his coat. What is Fain telling her? What does he know?

lɔɪəl, ət list, dɪd nɑt lʊk wɝid. ði oʊɡiɝ wɑz stʌɾiɪŋ ðə wɔlz. fɝst i hæd stʊɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə ɹum ən stɛɹd, tɝnɪŋ sloʊli ɪn ə sɝkəl; naʊ hi wɑz ɔlmoʊs pɹɛsɪŋ ɪz bɹɔd noʊz əɡɛns ðə stoʊn waɪl i dʒɛnli tʃɹeɪst ə pɝtɪkjəlɝ dʒɔɪn wɪð fɪŋɡɝz θɪkɝ ðən moʊs mɛnz θʌmz. səmtaɪmz i kloʊzd ɪz aɪz, əz ɪf ðə filɪŋ wɑz mɔɹ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ðən siɪŋ. hɪz ɪɹz ɡeɪv ən əkeɪʒənəl twɪtʃ, ən i mʌɾɝd tə hɪmsɛlf ɪn oʊɡiɝ, əpɪɹɪŋ tə hæv fɝɡɑɾən ɛniwʌn ɛls wɑz ɪn ðə ɹum wɪð hɪm.

Loial, at least, did not look worried. The Ogier was studying the walls. First he had stood in the middle of the room and stared, turning slowly in a circle; now he was almost pressing his broad nose against the stone while he gently traced a particular join with fingers thicker than most men's thumbs. Sometimes he closed his eyes, as if the feeling was more important than seeing. His ears gave an occasional twitch, and he muttered to himself in Ogier, appearing to have forgotten anyone else was in the room with him.

lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ stʊd tɔkɪŋ kwaɪətli wɪð nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə lɔŋ faɪɝpleɪs ət ði ɛn ə ðə ɹum. hi wɑz ə ɡʊd hoʊst, ədɛpt ət meɪkɪŋ pipəl fɝɡɛt ðɛɹ tʃɹʌbəlz; sɛvɹəl ə hɪz stɔɹiz hæɾ ɛɡwin ɪn ɡɪɡəlz. wʌns ivən nɪneɪiv θɹu bæk əɹ hɛɾ ən ɹɔɹd wɪð læftɝ. ɹænd ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ət ði ʌnɪkspɛktɪd saʊnd, ən dʒʌmpt əɡɛn wən mæts tʃɛɹ kɹæʃt tə ðə flɔɹ.

Lord Agelmar stood talking quietly with Nynaeve and Egwene in front of the long fireplace at the end of the room. He was a good host, adept at making people forget their troubles; several of his stories had Egwene in giggles. Once even Nynaeve threw back her head and roared with laughter. Rand gave a start at the unexpected sound, and jumped again when Mat's chair crashed to the floor.

"blʌɾ ən æʃəz!" mæt ɡɹaʊld, ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə weɪ nɪneɪivz maʊθ taɪɾənd əɾ ɪz læŋɡwədʒ. "wʌts teɪkɪŋ əɹ soʊ lɔŋ?" hi ɹaɪɾɪd ɪz tʃɛɹ ən sæt bæk daʊn wɪθaʊt lʊkɪŋ əɾ ɛniwʌn. hɪz hæn stʃɹeɪd tə hɪz koʊt.

"Blood and ashes!" Mat growled, ignoring the way Nynaeve's mouth tightened at his language. "What's taking her so long?" He righted his chair and sat back down without looking at anyone. His hand strayed to his coat.

ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə lʊkt ət mæt dɪsəpɹuvɪŋli - hɪz ɡeɪz tʊk ɪn ɹænd ən pɛɹɪn wɪθaʊɾ ɛni ɪmpɹuvmənt - ðən tɝn bæk tə ðə wɪmən. ɹændz peɪsɪŋ hæd teɪkən ɪm kloʊs tə ðɛm.

The Lord of Fal Dara looked at Mat disapprovingly - his gaze took in Rand and Perrin without any improvement - then turned back to the women. Rand's pacing had taken him close to them.

"maɪ lɔɹd," ɛɡwin wɑz seɪɪŋ, əz ɡlɪbli əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn juzɪŋ taɪɾəlz ɔl ə hɝ laɪf, "aɪ θɔɾ i wɑz ə wɔɹɾɝ, bʌt jə kɔl ɪm daɪ ʃæn, ən tɔk əbaʊɾ ə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn bænɝ, ən soʊ dɪd ðoʊz ʌðɝ mɛn. səmtaɪmz jə saʊn ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf hiz ə kɪŋ. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ wʌns mɔɪɹeɪn kɔld ɪm ðə læs lɔɹɾ ə ðə sɛvən taʊɝz. hu ɪz hi?"

"My Lord," Egwene was saying, as glibly as if she had been using titles all of her life, "I thought he was a Warder, but you call him Dai Shan, and talk about a Golden Crane banner, and so did those other men. Sometimes you sound almost as if he's a king. I remember once Moiraine called him the last Lord of the Seven Towers. Who is he?"

nɪneɪiv bɪɡæn stʌɾiɪŋ əɹ kʌp ɪntɛnli, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɑbviəs tə ɹænd ðəɾ əbɹʌpli ʃi wɑz lɪsnɪŋ ivən mɔɹ kloʊsli ðən wɑz ɛɡwin. ɹænd stɑpt ən tʃɹaɪd tə oʊvɝhɪɹ wɪθaʊt simɪŋ tə ivzdʒɹɑp.

Nynaeve began studying her cup intently, but it was obvious to Rand that abruptly she was listening even more closely than was Egwene. Rand stopped and tried to overhear without seeming to eavesdrop.

"lɔɹɾ ə ðə sɛvən taʊɝz," eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd wɪð ə fɹaʊn. "æn eɪntʃən taɪɾəl, leɪɾi ɛɡwin. nɑɾ ivən ðə haɪ lɔɹdz ə tiɹ əv oʊldɝ, ðoʊ ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ kʌmz kloʊs." hi hivd ə saɪ, ən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "hi wɪl nɑt spik ʌv ɪt, jɛt ðə stɔɹi ɪz wɛl noʊn əlɔŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝ. hiz ə kɪŋ, əɹ ʃəɾ əv bɪn, ælən mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən, lɔɹɾ ə ðə sɛvən taʊɝz, lɔɹɾ ə ðə leɪks, kɹaʊnləs kɪŋ ə ðə mɔlkɪɹi." hɪz ʃeɪvən hɛd lɪftəd haɪ, ən ðəɹ wɑz ə laɪɾ ɪn ɪz aɪ əz ɪf i fɛlt ə fɑðɝz pɹaɪd. hɪz vɔɪs ɡɹu stʃɹɔŋɝ, fɪld wɪð ðə fɔɹs ə hɪz filɪŋ. ðə hoʊl ɹum kəd hɪɹ wɪθaʊt stʃɹeɪnɪŋ. "wi ʌv ʃaɪnɝ kɔl aʊɝsɛlvz bɔɹɾɝmɪn, bʌt fjuɝ ðən fɪfti jɪɹz əɡoʊ, ʃaɪnɝ wɑz nɑt tʃɹuli ʌv ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. nɔɹθ ʌv ʌs, ən ə ɝæfəl, wɑz mɔlkiɝ. ðə lænsɪz ə ʃaɪnɝ ɹoʊd nɔɹθ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz mɔlkiɝ ðət hɛl bæk ðə blaɪt. mɔlkiɝ, pis feɪvɝ əɹ mɛmɹi, ən ðə laɪɾ ɪlumin əɹ neɪm."

"Lord of the Seven Towers," Agelmar said with a frown. "An ancient title, Lady Egwene. Not even the High Lords of Tear have older, though the Queen of Andor comes close." He heaved a sigh, and shook his head. "He will not speak of it, yet the story is well known along the Border. He is a king, or should have been, al'Lan Mandragoran, Lord of the Seven Towers, Lord of the Lakes, crownless King of the Malkieri." His shaven head lifted high, and there was a light in his eye as if he felt a father's pride. His voice grew stronger, filled with the force of his feeling. The whole room could hear without straining. "We of Shienar call ourselves Bordermen, but fewer than fifty years ago, Shienar was not truly of the Borderlands. North of us, and of Arafel, was Malkier. The lances of Shienar rode north, but it was Malkier that held back the Blight. Malkier, Peace favor her memory, and the Light illumine her name."

"læn ɪz fɹəm mɔlkiɝ," ðə wɪzdəm sɛd sɔfli, lʊkɪŋ ʌp. ʃi sim tʃɹʌbəld.

"Lan is from Malkier," the Wisdom said softly, looking up. She seemed troubled.

ɪt wɑz nɑɾ ə kwɛstʃən, bʌɾ eɪɡəlmɝ nɑɾəd. "jɛs, leɪɾi nɪneɪiv, hiz ðə sʌn ʌv əlækɹ mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən, læs kɹaʊn kɪŋ ə ðə mɔlkɪɹi. haʊ dɪɾ i bɪkʌm əz i ɪz? ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ, pɝhæps, wɑz leɪn. ɑn ə dɛɹ, leɪn mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən, ðə kɪŋz bɹʌðɝ, lɛɾ ɪz lænsɪz θɹu ðə blaɪt tə ðə blæstəd lænz, pɝhæps tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl ɪtsɛlf. leɪnz waɪf, bɹeɪən, meɪd ðət dɛɹ fəɹ ði ɛnvi ðət bɝn əɹ hɑɹt ðəɾ əlækɹ hæd bɪn ɹeɪz tə ðə θɹoʊn ɪnstɛɾ ə leɪn. ðə kɪŋ ən leɪn wɝ əz kloʊz əz bɹʌðɝz kəd bi, əz kloʊz əz twɪnz ivən æftɝ ðə ɹɔɪəl 'æl' wɑz æɾəd tə əkɪɹz neɪm, bʌt dʒɛləsi ɹæk bɹeɪən. leɪn wɑz əkleɪm fəɹ ɪz didz, ən ɹaɪtfəli soʊ, bʌt nɑɾ ivən i kəɾ aʊtʃaɪn əlækɹ. hi wɑz, mæn ən kɪŋ, sətʃ əz kʌmz wʌns ɪn ə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ɪf ðæt. pis feɪvɝ hɪm, ən ɛlinə.

It was not a question, but Agelmar nodded. "Yes, Lady Nynaeve, he is the son of al'Akir Mandragoran, last crowned King of the Malkieri. How did he become as he is? The beginning, perhaps, was Lain. On a dare, Lain Mandragoran, the King's brother, led his lances through the Blight to the Blasted Lands, perhaps to Shayol Ghul itself. Lain's wife, Breyan, made that dare for the envy that burned her heart that al'Akir had been raised to the throne instead of Lain. The King and Lain were as close as brothers could be, as close as twins even after the royal 'al' was added to Akir's name, but jealousy wracked Breyan. Lain was acclaimed for his deeds, and rightfully so, but not even he could outshine al'Akir. He was, man and king, such as comes once in a hundred years, if that. Peace favor him, and el'Leanna.

"leɪn daɪɾ ɪn ðə blæstəd lænz wɪð moʊst ə ðoʊz u fɑloʊd hɪm, mɛn mɔlkiɝ kəɾ ɪl əfɔɹd tə luz, ən bɹeɪən bleɪm ðə kɪŋ, seɪɪŋ ðət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl ɪtsɛlf wʊɾə fɔlən ɪf əlækɹ hæd lɛd ðə ɹɛst ə ðə mɔlkɪɹi nɔɹθ wɪð əɹ hʌzbənd. fəɹ ɹivɛnʒ, ʃi plɑɾəd wɪð kaʊɪn ɡəmælən, kɔl kaʊɪn fɛɹhɑɹt, tə siz ðə θɹoʊn fəɹ əɹ sʌn, ɪsəm. naʊ fɛɹhɑɹt wɑz ə hɪɹoʊ ɔlmoʊst əz wɛl lʌvd əz əlækɹ hɪmsɛlf, ən wʌn ə ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz, bʌt wən ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz hæd kæs ðə ɹɑdz fəɹ kɪŋ, oʊnli tu sɛpɝeɪɾəd ɪm fɹəm əkɪɹ, ən i nɛvɝ fɝɡɑt ðət tu mɛn leɪɪŋ ə dɪfɹən kʌlɝ ɑn ðə kɹaʊnɪŋ stoʊn wʊɾə sɛɾ ɪm ɑn ðə θɹoʊn ɪnstɛd. bɪtwin ðɛm, kaʊɪn ən bɹeɪən muv soʊlʒɝz bæk fɹəm ðə blaɪt tə siz ðə sɛvən taʊɝz, stʃɹɪpɪŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝfɔɹts tə bɛɹ ɡæɹɪsənz.

"Lain died in the Blasted Lands with most of those who followed him, men Malkier could ill afford to lose, and Breyan blamed the King, saying that Shayol Ghul itself would have fallen if al'Akir had led the rest of the Malkieri north with her husband. For revenge, she plotted with Cowin Gemallan, called Cowin Fairheart, to seize the throne for her son, Isam. Now Fairheart was a hero almost as well loved as al'Akir himself, and one of the Great Lords, but when the Great Lords had cast the rods for king, only two separated him from Akir, and he never forgot that two men laying a different color on the Crowning Stone would have set him on the throne instead. Between them, Cowin and Breyan moved soldiers back from the Blight to seize the Seven Towers, stripping the Borderforts to bare garrisons.

"bʌt kaʊɪnz dʒɛləsi ɹæn dipɝ." dɪsɡʌs tɪŋd eɪɡəlmɝz vɔɪs. "fɛɹhɑɹt ðə hɪɹoʊ, huz ɛksplɔɪts ɪn ðə blaɪt wɝ sʌŋ θɹuaʊt ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, wɑz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd. wɪð ðə bɔɹɾɝfɔɹts wikənd, tʃɹɑləks pɔɹɾ ɪndə mɔlkiɝ laɪk ə flʌd. kɪŋ əlækɹ ən leɪn təɡɛðɝ maɪɾ əv ɹælid ðə lænd; ðeɪ hæd dʌn soʊ bɪfɔɹ. bʌt leɪnz dum ɪn ðə blæstəd lænz hæd ʃeɪkən ðə pipəl, ən ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ɪnveɪʒən bɹoʊk mɛnz spɪɹəɾ ən ðɛɹ wɪl tə ɹɪzɪst. tu mɛni mɛn. oʊvɝwɛlmɪŋ nʌmbɝz pʊʃt ðə mɔlkɪɹi bæk ɪndə ðə hɑɹtlænd.

"But Cowin's jealousy ran deeper." Disgust tinged Agelmar's voice. "Fairheart the hero, whose exploits in the Blight were sung throughout the Borderlands, was a Darkfriend. With the Borderforts weakened, Trollocs poured into Malkier like a flood. King al'Akir and Lain together might have rallied the land; they had done so before. But Lain's doom in the Blasted Lands had shaken the people, and the Trolloc invasion broke men's spirit and their will to resist. Too many men. Overwhelming numbers pushed the Malkieri back into the heartland.

"bɹeɪən flɛd wɪð əɹ ɪnfən sʌn ɪsəm, ən wɑz ɹʌn daʊn baɪ tʃɹɑləks əz ʃi ɹoʊd saʊθ wɪð hɪm. noʊ wʌn noʊz ðɛɹ feɪɾ ʌv ə sɝɾənti, bʌɾ ɪt kən bi ɡɛst. aɪ kən faɪn pɪɾi oʊnli fəɹ ðə bɔɪ. wən kaʊɪn fɛɹhɑɹts tʃɹɛtʃɝi wɑz ɹɪvild ən i wɑz teɪkən baɪ jʌŋ dʒaɪn tʃɛɝɪn - ɔlɹɛɾi kɔl dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ - wən fɛɹhɑɹt wɑz bɹɔt tə ðə sɛvən taʊɝz ɪn tʃeɪnz, ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹdz kɔl fəɹ ɪz hɛɾ ɑn ə paɪk. bʌt kəz i hæd bɪn sɛkən oʊnli tə əlækɹ ən leɪn ɪn ðə hɑɹts ə ðə pipəl, ðə kɪŋ feɪst ɪm ɪn sɪŋɡəl kɑmbæɾ ən slu hɪm. əlækɹ wɛpt wən i kɪl kaʊɪn. səm seɪ hi wɛp fəɹ ə fɹɛn u hæd ɡɪvən hɪmsɛlf tə ðə ʃædoʊ, ən səm seɪ fəɹ mɔlkiɝ." ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə ʃʊk ɪz hɛd sædli.

"Breyan fled with her infant son Isam, and was run down by Trollocs as she rode south with him. No one knows their fate of a certainty, but it can be guessed. I can find pity only for the boy. When Cowin Fairheart's treachery was revealed and he was taken by young Jain Charin - already called Jain Farstrider - when Fairheart was brought to the Seven Towers in chains, the Great Lords called for his head on a pike. But because he had been second only to al'Akir and Lain in the hearts of the people, the King faced him in single combat and slew him. Al'Akir wept when he killed Cowin. Some say he wept for a friend who had given himself to the Shadow, and some say for Malkier." The Lord of Fal Dara shook his head sadly.

"ðə fɝs pil ə ðə dum ə ðə sɛvən taʊɝz hæd bɪn stʃɹʌk. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ taɪm tə ɡæðɝ eɪd fɹəm ʃaɪnɝ əɹ ɝæfəl, ən noʊ hoʊp ðət mɔlkiɝ kəd stæn əloʊn, wɪð faɪv θaʊzən ə hɝ lænsɪz dɛɾ ɪn ðə blæstəd lænz, hɝ bɔɹɾɝfɔɹts oʊvɝɹʌn.

"The first peal of the doom of the Seven Towers had been struck. There was no time to gather aid from Shienar or Arafel, and no hope that Malkier could stand alone, with five thousand of her lances dead in the Blasted Lands, her Borderforts overrun.

"əlækɹ ən ɪz kwin, ɛlinə, hæd læn bɹɔt tə ðɛm ɪn ɪz kɹeɪɾəl. ɪndə hɪz ɪnfən hænz ðeɪ pleɪs ðə sɔɹɾ ə mɔlkɪɹi kɪŋz, ðə sɔɹɾ i wɛɹz tədeɪ. ə wɛpən meɪd baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə paʊɝ, ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ ðət bɹɔt daʊn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ðeɪ ənɔɪntəɾ ɪz hɛd wɪð ɔɪl, neɪmɪŋ ɪm daɪ ʃæn, ə daɪəɾɪmd bæɾəl lɔɹd, ən kɑnsəkɹeɪɾəd ɪm əz ðə nɛks kɪŋ ə ðə mɔlkɪɹi, ən ɪn ɪz neɪm ðeɪ swɔɹ ði eɪntʃən oʊθ ə mɔlkɪɹi kɪŋz ən kwinz." eɪɡəlmɝz feɪs hɑɹɾənd, ən i spoʊk ðə wɝdz əz ɪf hi, tu, hæd swɔɹn ðəɾ oʊθ, əɹ wʌn mʌtʃ sɪməlɝ. "tə stæn əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ soʊ lɔŋ əz aɪɝn ɪz hɑɹɾ ən stoʊn əbaɪdz. tə dɪfɛn ðə mɔlkɪɹi waɪl wʌn dʒɹɑp ə blʌd ɹɪmeɪnz. tə əvɛnʒ wʌt kænɑt bi dɪfɛndəd." ðə wɝdz ɹæŋ ɪn ðə tʃeɪmbɝ.

"Al'Akir and his Queen, el'Leanna, had Lan brought to them in his cradle. Into his infant hands they placed the sword of Malkieri kings, the sword he wears today. A weapon made by Aes Sedai during the War of Power, the War of the Shadow that brought down the Age of Legends. They anointed his head with oil, naming him Dai Shan, a Diademed Battle Lord, and consecrated him as the next King of the Malkieri, and in his name they swore the ancient oath of Malkieri kings and queens." Agelmar's face hardened, and he spoke the words as if he, too, had sworn that oath, or one much similar. "To stand against the Shadow so long as iron is hard and stone abides. To defend the Malkieri while one drop of blood remains. To avenge what cannot be defended." The words rang in the chamber.

"ɛlinə pleɪst ə lɑkəɾ ɝaʊn əɹ sʌnz nɛk, fəɹ ɹimɛmbɹəns, ən ði ɪnfənt, ɹæpt ɪn swɑɾəlɪŋ kloʊðz baɪ ðə kwinz oʊn hænd, wɑz ɡɪvən oʊvɝ tə twɛnti tʃoʊzən fɹəm ðə kɪŋz bɑɾiɡɑɹd, ðə bɛst sɔɝdzmɪn, ðə moʊs dɛdli faɪɾɝz. ðɛɹ kəmænd: tə kæɹi ðə tʃaɪl tə fæl mɝæn.

"El'Leanna placed a locket around her son's neck, for remembrance, and the infant, wrapped in swaddling clothes by the Queen's own hand, was given over to twenty chosen from the King's Bodyguard, the best swordsmen, the most deadly fighters. Their command: to carry the child to Fal Moran.

"ðɛn dɪɾ əlækɹ ən ɛlinə lɛd ðə mɔlkɪɹi aʊt tə feɪs ðə ʃædoʊ wʌn læs taɪm. ðəɹ ðeɪ daɪd, ət hɪɹæts kɹɔsɪŋ, ən ðə mɔlkɪɹi daɪd, ən ðə sɛvən taʊɝz wɝ bɹoʊkən. ʃaɪnɝ, ən ɝæfəl, ən kændɝ, mɛt ðə hæfmən ən ðə tʃɹɑləks ət ðə stɛɹ ə dʒəhɑn ən θɹu ðɛm bæk, bʌt nɑɾ əz fɑɹ əz ðeɪ hæd bɪn. moʊst ə mɔlkiɝ ɹɪmeɪn ɪn tʃɹɑlɑk hænz, ən jɪɹ baɪ jɪɹ, maɪl baɪ maɪl, ðə blaɪɾ əz swɑloʊɾ ɪt." eɪɡəlmɝ dʒɹu ə hɛvaɪɑɹɾɪd bɹɛθ. wən i wɛn ɑn, ðəɹ wɑz ə sæd pɹaɪɾ ɪn ɪz aɪz ən vɔɪs.

"Then did al'Akir and el'Leanna lead the Malkieri out to face the Shadow one last time. There they died, at Herat's Crossing, and the Malkieri died, and the Seven Towers were broken. Shienar, and Arafel, and Kandor, met the Halfmen and the Trollocs at the Stair of Jehaan and threw them back, but not as far as they had been. Most of Malkier remained in Trolloc hands, and year by year, mile by mile, the Blight has swallowed it." Agelmar drew a heavyhearted breath. When he went on, there was a sad pride in his eyes and voice.

"oʊnli faɪv ə ðə bɑɾiɡɑɹdz ɹitʃt fæl mɝæn əlaɪv, ɛvɹi mæn wundəd, bʌt ðeɪ hæd ðə tʃaɪld ənhɑɹmd. fɹəm ðə kɹeɪɾəl ðeɪ tɔɾ ɪm ɔl ðeɪ nu. hi lɝnd wɛpənz əz ʌðɝ tʃɪlʒɹən lɝn tɔɪz, ən ðə blaɪɾ əz ʌðɝ tʃɪlʒɹən ðɛɹ mʌðɝz ɡɑɹɾən. ði oʊθ swɔɹn oʊvɝ ɪz kɹeɪɾəl ɪz ɡɹeɪvən ɪn ɪz maɪnd. ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ lɛf tə dɪfɛnd, bʌɾ i kən əvɛnʒ. hi dɪnaɪz ɪz taɪɾəlz, jɛɾ ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz hiz kɔl ði ʌnkɹoʊnd, ən ɪf ɛvɝ i ɹeɪz ðə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn ə mɔlkiɝ, ən ɑɹmi wəd kʌm tə fɑloʊ. bʌt hɪl nɑt lɛd mɛn tə ðɛɹ dɛθs. ɪn ðə blaɪɾ i kɔɹts dɛθ əz ə suɾɝ kɔɹts ə meɪɾən, bʌt hɪl nɑt lɛɾ ʌðɝz tə ɪt.

"Only five of the Bodyguards reached Fal Moran alive, every man wounded, but they had the child unharmed. From the cradle they taught him all they knew. He learned weapons as other children learn toys, and the Blight as other children their mother's garden. The oath sworn over his cradle is graven in his mind. There is nothing left to defend, but he can avenge. He denies his titles, yet in the Borderlands he is called the Uncrowned, and if ever he raised the Golden Crane of Malkier, an army would come to follow. But he will not lead men to their deaths. In the Blight he courts death as a suitor courts a maiden, but he will not lead others to it.

"ɪf jə mʌst ɛntɝ ðə blaɪt, ən wɪð oʊnli ə fju, ðəɹ ɪz noʊ mæn bɛɾɝ tə teɪk jə ðɛɹ, nɔɹ tə bɹɪŋ jə seɪfli aʊɾ əɡɛn. hiz ðə bɛst ə ðə wɔɹɾɝz, ən ðət minz ðə bɛst ə ðə bɛst. jə maɪɾ əz wɛl liv ðiz bɔɪz hɪɹ, tə ɡeɪn ə lɪɾəl sizənɪŋ, ən pʊt jəɹ ɪntaɪɝ tʃɹʌst ɪn læn. ðə blaɪɾ ɪz noʊ pleɪs fəɹ əntʃɹaɪd bɔɪz."

"If you must enter the Blight, and with only a few, there is no man better to take you there, nor to bring you safely out again. He is the best of the Warders, and that means the best of the best.
