You might as well leave these boys here, to gain a little seasoning, and put your entire trust in Lan. The Blight is no place for untried boys."

mæt oʊpən ɪz maʊθ, ən ʃʌɾ ɪɾ əɡɛn əɾ ə lʊk fɹəm ɹænd. aɪ wɪʃ hid lɝn tə kip ɪt ʃʌt.

Mat opened his mouth, and shut it again at a look from Rand. I wish he'd learn to keep it shut.

nɪneɪiv hæd lɪsən dʒʌst əz waɪd-aɪɾ əz ɛɡwin, bʌt naʊ ʃi wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ɪndə hɝ kʌp əɡɛn, hɝ feɪs peɪl. ɛɡwin pʊɾ ə hæn ɑn əɹ ɑɹm ən ɡeɪv əɹ ə sɪmpəθɛɾɪk lʊk.

Nynaeve had listened just as wide-eyed as Egwene, but now she was staring into her cup again, her face pale. Egwene put a hand on her arm and gave her a sympathetic look.

mɔɪɹeɪn əpɪɹɾ ɪn ðə dɔɹweɪ, læn əɾ əɹ hilz. nɪneɪiv tɝn əɹ bæk ɑn ðɛm.

Moiraine appeared in the doorway, Lan at her heels. Nynaeve turned her back on them.

"wʌt dɪɾ i seɪ?" ɹænd dɪmændəd. mæt ɹoʊz, ən pɛɹɪn, tu.

"What did he say?" Rand demanded. Mat rose, and Perrin, too.

"kʌntʃɹi ɑf," eɪɡəlmɝ mʌɾɝd, ðən ɹeɪzd ɪz vɔɪs tə ə nɔɹməl toʊn. "dɪd jə lɝn ɛniθɪŋ, ɛɛs sədaɪ, əɹ ɪz i sɪmpli ə mædmæn?"

"Country oaf," Agelmar muttered, then raised his voice to a normal tone. "Did you learn anything, Aes Sedai, or is he simply a madman?"

"hi ɪz mæd," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "ɔɹ kloʊs tə ɪt, bʌt ðəɹ ɪz nʌθɪŋ sɪmpəl əbaʊt pdən feɪn." wʌn ə ðə blæk-ænd-ɡoʊld-lɪvɹid sɝvəns baʊɾ ɪz weɪ ɪn wɪð ə blu wɑʃbeɪsən ən pɪtʃɝ, ə bɑɹ ə jɛloʊ soʊp, ən ə smɔl taʊəl ɑn ə sɪlvɝ tʃɹeɪ; hi lʊkt æŋkʃəsli əɾ eɪɡəlmɝ. mɔɪɹeɪn dɝɛktəɾ ɪm tə pʊɾ əm ɑn ðə teɪbəl. "jɔɹ pɑɹɾən fəɹ kəmændɪŋ jəɹ sɝvəns, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ," ʃi sɛd. "aɪ tʊk ðə lɪbɝɾi ʌv æskɪŋ fəɹ ðɪs."

"He is mad," Moiraine said, "or close to it, but there is nothing simple about Padan Fain." One of the black-and-gold-liveried servants bowed his way in with a blue washbasin and pitcher, a bar of yellow soap, and a small towel on a silver tray; he looked anxiously at Agelmar. Moiraine directed him to put them on the table. "Your pardon for commanding your servants, Lord Agelmar," she said. "I took the liberty of asking for this."

eɪɡəlmɝ nɑɾəd tə ðə sɝvənt, hu pʊt ðə tʃɹeɪ ɑn ðə teɪbəl ən lɛf hɝidli. "maɪ sɝvəns ɑɹ jʊɹz tə kəmænd, ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Agelmar nodded to the servant, who put the tray on the table and left hurriedly. "My servants are yours to command, Aes Sedai."

ðə wɔɾɝ mɔɪɹeɪn pɔɹɾ ɪndə ðə beɪsən stimd əz ɪf oʊnli dʒʌst ɔf ðə bɔɪl. ʃi pʊʃt ʌp əɹ slivz ən bɪɡæn vɪɡɝəsli wɑʃɪŋ əɹ hænz wɪθaʊt ɹəɡɑɹd fəɹ ðə hiɾ ə ðə wɔɾɝ. "aɪ sɛɾ i wɑz wɝs ðən vaɪl, bʌɾ aɪ dɪd nɑt kʌm kloʊs. aɪ də nɑt bɪliv aɪ hæv ɛvɝ mɛt sʌmwʌn soʊ æbʒɛkt ən dəbeɪst, jɛɾ ət ðə seɪm taɪm soʊ faʊl. aɪ fil sɔɪl fɹəm tʌtʃɪŋ hɪm, ən aɪ də nɑt min fəɹ ðə fɪlθ ɑn ɪz skɪn. sɔɪld ɪn hɪɹ." ʃi tʌtʃt əɹ bɹɛst. "ðə dɛɡɹədeɪʃən ə hɪz soʊl ɔlmoʊs meɪks mi daʊt hiz wʌn. ðəɹ ɪz sʌmθɪŋ wɝs tə hɪm ðən ə dɑɹkfɹɛnd."

The water Moiraine poured into the basin steamed as if only just off the boil. She pushed up her sleeves and began vigorously washing her hands without regard for the heat of the water. "I said he was worse than vile, but I did not come close. I do not believe I have ever met someone so abject and debased, yet at the same time so foul. I feel soiled from touching him, and I do not mean for the filth on his skin. Soiled in here." She touched her breast. "The degradation of his soul almost makes me doubt he has one. There is something worse to him than a Darkfriend."

"hi lʊk soʊ pɪɾəfəl," ɛɡwin mɝmɝd. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ɪm ɝaɪvɪŋ ɪn ɛmənz fild itʃ spɹɪŋ, ɔlweɪz læfɪŋ ən fʊl ə nuz fɹəm aʊtsaɪd. ʃʊɹli ðɛɹz səm hoʊp fəɹ hɪm? 'noʊ mæn kən stæn ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ soʊ lɔŋ ðəɾ i kænɑt faɪn ðə laɪɾ əɡɛn,' " ʃi kwoʊɾəd.

"He looked so pitiful," Egwene murmured. "I remember him arriving in Emond's Field each spring, always laughing and full of news from outside. Surely there's some hope for him? 'No man can stand in the Shadow so long that he cannot find the Light again,' " she quoted.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ taʊəld əɹ hænz bɹɪskli. "aɪ hæv ɔlweɪz bɪlivd ɪt soʊ," ʃi sɛd. "pɝhæps pdən feɪn kən bi ɹɪdimd. bʌt hiz bɪn ə dɑɹkfɹɛn mɔɹ ðən fɔɹɾi jɪɹz, ən wʌt hiz dʌn fəɹ ðæt, ɪn blʌɾ ən peɪn ən dɛθ, wəd fɹiz jəɹ hɑɹt tə hɪɹ. əmʌŋ ðə list ə ðiz - ðoʊ nɑt smɔl tə ju, aɪ səspɛkt - hi bɹɔt ðə tʃɹɑləks tə ɛmənz fild."

The Aes Sedai toweled her hands briskly. "I have always believed it so," she said. "Perhaps Padan Fain can be redeemed. But he has been a Darkfriend more than forty years, and what he has done for that, in blood and pain and death, would freeze your heart to hear. Among the least of these - though not small to you, I suspect - he brought the Trollocs to Emond's Field."

"jɛs," ɹænd sɛd sɔfli. hi hɝɾ ɛɡwin ɡæsp. aɪ ʃəɾ əv ɡɛst. bɝn mi, aɪ ʃəd hæv, əz sun əz aɪ ɹɛkəɡnaɪz hɪm.

"Yes," Rand said softly. He heard Egwene gasp. I should have guessed. Burn me, I should have, as soon as I recognized him.

"dɪɾ i bɹɪŋ ɛni hɪɹ?" mæt æskt. hi lʊkt ət ðə stoʊn wɔlz ɝaʊn əm ən ʃɪvɝd. ɹænd θɔɾ i wɑz ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðə mɪdʒɹɑl mɔɹ ðən tʃɹɑləks; wɔlz hæd nɑt stɑp ðə feɪɾ ət bɛɹlən, əɹ ət waɪtbɹɪdʒ.

"Did he bring any here?" Mat asked. He looked at the stone walls around them and shivered. Rand thought he was remembering the Myddraal more than Trollocs; walls had not stopped the Fade at Baerlon, or at Whitebridge.

"ɪf i dɪd" - eɪɡəlmɝ læft - "ðeɪl bɹeɪk ðɛɹ tiθ ɑn ðə wɔlz ə fæl dæɹə. mɛni ʌðɝz əv bɪfɔɹ." hi wɑz spikɪŋ tə ɛvɹiwʌn, bʌɾ ɑbviəsli ədʒɹɛsɪŋ ɪz wɝdz tə ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv, fɹəm ðə ɡlænsɪz i ɡeɪv ðɛm. "æn də nɑt wɝi jɝsɛlf əbaʊt hæfmən, iðɝ." mæts feɪs ɹɛɾənd. "ɛvɹi stʃɹiɾ ən æli ɪn fæl dæɹə ɪz lɪt baɪ naɪt. ən noʊ mæn meɪ haɪɾ ɪz feɪs ɪnsaɪd ðə wɔlz."

"If he did" - Agelmar laughed - "they'll break their teeth on the walls of Fal Dara. Many others have before." He was speaking to everyone, but obviously addressing his words to Egwene and Nynaeve, from the glances he gave them. "And do not worry yourself about Halfmen, either." Mat's face reddened. "Every street and alley in Fal Dara is lit by night. And no man may hide his face inside the walls."

"waɪ wəd mæstɝ feɪn də ðæt?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"Why would Master Fain do that?" Egwene asked.

"θɹi jɪɹz əɡoʊ. . . ." wɪð ə hɛvi saɪ mɔɪɹeɪn sæt daʊn, foʊldɪŋ ʌp əz ɪf wʌt ʃi hæd dʌn wɪð feɪn hæd dʒɹeɪn hɝ. "θɹi jɪɹz, ðɪs sʌmɝ. əz fɑɹ bæk əz ðæt. ðə laɪt ʃʊɹli feɪvɝz ʌs, ɛls ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz wʊɾə tʃɹaɪəmft waɪl aɪ stɪl sæt plænɪŋ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. θɹi jɪɹz, feɪn əz bɪn hʌntɪŋ jə fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn."

"Three years ago. . . ." With a heavy sigh Moiraine sat down, folding up as if what she had done with Fain had drained her. "Three years, this summer. As far back as that. The Light surely favors us, else the Father of Lies would have triumphed while I still sat planning in Tar Valon. Three years, Fain has been hunting you for the Dark One."

"ðæts kɹeɪzi!" ɹænd sɛd. "hiz kʌm ɪndə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ɛvɹi spɹɪŋ əz ɹɛɡjəlɝ əz ə klɑk. θɹi jɪɹz? wiv bɪn ɹaɪt ðəɹ ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ən i nɛvɝ lʊkt əɾ ɛni ʌv əs twaɪs bɪfɔɹ læs jɪɹ." ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pɔɪntəɾ ə fɪŋɡɝ ət hɪm, fɪksɪŋ hɪm.

"That's crazy!" Rand said. "He's come into the Two Rivers every spring as regular as a clock. Three years? We've been right there in front of him, and he never looked at any of us twice before last year." The Aes Sedai pointed a finger at him, fixing him.

"feɪn toʊl mi ɛvɹiθɪŋ, ɹænd. əɹ ɔlmoʊst ɛvɹiθɪŋ. aɪ bɪliv i mænədʒ tə hoʊl bæk sʌmθɪŋ, sʌmθɪŋ ɪmpɔɹɾənt, dɪspaɪɾ ɔl aɪ kəd du, bʌɾ i sɛɾ ɪnʌf. θɹi jɪɹz əɡoʊ, ə hæfmən keɪm fəɹ ɪm ɪn ə taʊn ɪn mʊɹændi. feɪn wɑz tɛɹəfaɪd, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ɪts kənsɪɾɝd ə vɛɹi ɡɹeɪɾ ɑnɝ əmʌŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz tə bi soʊ sʌmənd. feɪn bɪlivd i hæd bɪn tʃoʊzən fəɹ ɡɹeɪt θɪŋz, ən i hæd, ðoʊ nɑɾ ɪn ðə mænɝ i bɪlivd. hi wɑz bɹɔt nɔɹθ tə ðə blaɪt, tə ðə blæstəd lænz. tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. wɛɹ i mɛɾ ə mæn wɪð aɪz ə faɪɝ, hu neɪm hɪmsɛlf bælzəmən."

"Fain told me everything, Rand. Or almost everything. I believe he managed to hold back something, something important, despite all I could do, but he said enough. Three years ago, a Halfman came for him in a town in Murandy. Fain was terrified, of course, but it is considered a very great honor among Darkfriends to be so summoned. Fain believed he had been chosen for great things, and he had, though not in the manner he believed. He was brought north to the Blight, to the Blasted Lands. To Shayol Ghul. Where he met a man with eyes of fire, who named himself Ba'alzamon."

mæt ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli, ən ɹænd swɑloʊd hɑɹd. ɪt hæd tə hæv bɪn ðət weɪ, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌt ðət dɪd nɑt meɪk ɪɾ ɛni iziɝ tə æksɛpt. oʊnli pɛɹɪn lʊkt ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ əz ɪf nʌθɪŋ kəd sɝpɹaɪz ɪm ɛni lɔŋɡɝ.

Mat shifted uneasily, and Rand swallowed hard. It had to have been that way, of course, but that did not make it any easier to accept. Only Perrin looked at the Aes Sedai as if nothing could surprise him any longer.

"ðə laɪt pɹətɛkt ʌs," eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd fɝvənli.

"The Light protect us," Agelmar said fervently.

"feɪn dɪd nɑt laɪk wʌt wɑz dʌn tə hɪm ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl," mɔɪɹeɪn kəntɪnjud kɑmli. "waɪl wi tɔkt, hi skɹimd ɔfən ə faɪɝ ən bɝnɪŋ. ɪɾ ɔlmoʊs kɪl hɪm, bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪɾ ɔl aʊt fɹəm wɛɹ i hæɾ ɪt hɪɾən. ivən wɪð maɪ hilɪŋ hiz ə ʃæɾɝd ɹuən. ɪɾəl teɪk mʌtʃ tə meɪk ɪm hoʊl əɡɛn. əl meɪk ði ɛfɝt, ðoʊ, ɪf fəɹ noʊ ʌðɝ ɹizən ðən tə lɝn wʌt mɔɹ i stɪl haɪdz. hi hæd bɪn tʃoʊzən kəz ʌv wɛɹ i dɪɾ ɪz pɛɾəlɪŋ. noʊ," ʃi sɛd kwɪkli wən ðeɪ stɝd, "nɑt ðə tu ɹɪvɝz oʊnli, nɑt ðɛn. ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz nu ɹʌfli wɛɹ tə faɪnd wʌɾ i sɔt, bʌt nɑt mʌtʃ bɛɾɝ ðən wi ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn.

"Fain did not like what was done to him at Shayol Ghul," Moiraine continued calmly. "While we talked, he screamed often of fire and burning. It almost killed him, bringing it all out from where he had it hidden. Even with my Healing he is a shattered ruin. It will take much to make him whole again. I will make the effort, though, if for no other reason than to learn what more he still hides. He had been chosen because of where he did his peddling. No," she said quickly when they stirred, "not the Two Rivers only, not then. The Father of Lies knew roughly where to find what he sought, but not much better than we in Tar Valon.

"feɪn sɛd hiz bɪn meɪd ðə dɑɹk wʌnz haʊnd, ən ɪn ə weɪ hiz ɹaɪt. ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz sɛt feɪn tə hʌnt, fɝs tʃeɪnʒɪŋ ɪm soʊ hi kəd kæɹi aʊt ðət hʌnt. ɪts ðə θɪŋz dʌn tə bɹɪŋ əbaʊt ðoʊz tʃeɪnʒəz ðət feɪn fɪɹz tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ; hi heɪts ɪz mæstɝ fəɹ əm əz mʌtʃ əz i fɪɹz hɪm. soʊ feɪn wɑz sɛn snɪfɪŋ ən hʌntɪŋ θɹu ɔl ðə vɪlədʒəz ɝaʊn bɛɹlən, ən ɔl ðə weɪ tə ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst, ən daʊn tə ðə tɛɹən ən əkɹɔs ɪndə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz."

"Fain said he has been made the Dark One's hound, and in a way he is right. The Father of Lies set Fain to hunt, first changing him so he could carry out that hunt. It is the things done to bring about those changes that Fain fears to remember; he hates his master for them as much as he fears him. So Fain was sent sniffing and hunting through all the villages around Baerlon, and all the way to the Mountains of Mist, and down to the Taren and across into the Two Rivers."

"θɹi spɹɪŋz əɡoʊ?" pɛɹɪn sɛd sloʊli. "aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðət spɹɪŋ. feɪn keɪm leɪɾɝ ðən juʒəwəl, bʌt wʌt wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒ wɑz ðəɾ i lɪŋɡɝɾ ɑn. ə hoʊl wik i ɹɪmeɪnd, aɪɾəl ən næʃɪŋ ɪz tiθ əbaʊt leɪɪŋ aʊt mʌni fəɹ ə ɹum ət ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ ɪn. feɪn laɪks ɪz mʌni."

"Three springs ago?" Perrin said slowly. "I remember that spring. Fain came later than usual, but what was strange was that he lingered on. A whole week he remained, idle and gnashing his teeth about laying out money for a room at the Winespring Inn. Fain likes his money."

"aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ, naʊ," mæt sɛd. "ɛvɹibɑɾi wɑz wʌndɝɪŋ wɑz i sɪk, əɹ hæɾ i fɔlən fəɹ ə loʊkəl wʊmən? nɑt ðəɾ ɛni ʌv əm wəd mɛɹi ə pɛdlɝ, ʌv kɔɹs. əz wɛl mɛɹi wʌn ə ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl." ɛɡwin ɹeɪzd ən aɪbɹaʊ ət hɪm, ən i ʃʌɾ ɪz maʊθ.

"I remember, now," Mat said. "Everybody was wondering was he sick, or had he fallen for a local woman? Not that any of them would marry a peddler, of course. As well marry one of the Traveling People." Egwene raised an eyebrow at him, and he shut his mouth.

"æftɝ ðæt, feɪn wɑz teɪkən tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl əɡɛn, ən ɪz maɪnd wɑz - dɪstɪld." ɹændz stʌmək tɝn oʊvɝ ət ðə toʊn ɪn ði ɛɛs sədaɪz vɔɪs; ɪt toʊl mɔɹ ʌv wʌt ʃi mɛn ðən ðə ɡɹɪmɑs ðət flæʃt əkɹɔs əɹ feɪs. "wʌɾ i hæd . . . sɛnst . . . wɑz kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ən fɛd bæk. wən i ɛntɝd ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ðə nɛks jɪɹ, hi wɑz eɪbəl tə tʃuz ɪz tɑɹɡəts aʊt mɔɹ klɪɹli. ɪndid, mɔɹ klɪɹli ivən ðən ðə dɑɹk wʌn hæɾ ɪkspɛktəd. feɪn nu fəɹ ə sɝɾənti ðət ðə wʌn i sɔt wɑz wʌn ə θɹi ɪn ɛmənz fild."

"After that, Fain was taken to Shayol Ghul again, and his mind was - distilled." Rand's stomach turned over at the tone in the Aes Sedai's voice; it told more of what she meant than the grimace that flashed across her face. "What he had . . . sensed . . . was concentrated and fed back. When he entered the Two Rivers the next year, he was able to choose his targets out more clearly. Indeed, more clearly even than the Dark One had expected. Fain knew for a certainty that the one he sought was one of three in Emond's Field."

pɛɹɪn ɡɹʌntɪd, ən mæt bɪɡæn kɝsɪŋ ɪn ə sɑf mɑnətoʊn ðəɾ ivən nɪneɪivz ɡlɛɹ dɪd nɑt stɑp. eɪɡəlmɝ lʊkt əɾ əm kjʊɹiəsli. ɹænd fɛlt oʊnli ðə feɪntəs tʃɪl, ən wʌndɝɾ əɾ ɪt. θɹi jɪɹz ðə dɑɹk wʌn hæd bɪn hʌntɪŋ ɪm . . . hʌntɪŋ ðɛm. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ɪt ʃʊɾə meɪɾ ɪz tiθ tʃæɾɝ.

Perrin grunted, and Mat began cursing in a soft monotone that even Nynaeve's glare did not stop. Agelmar looked at them curiously. Rand felt only the faintest chill, and wondered at it. Three years the Dark One had been hunting him . . . hunting them. He was sure it should have made his teeth chatter.

mɔɪɹeɪn dɪd nɑɾ əlaʊ mæt tə ɪntɝʌp hɝ. ʃi ɹeɪzd əɹ vɔɪs ɪnʌf tə bi hɝɾ oʊvɝ hɪm. "wɛn feɪn ɹɪtɝn tə luɡɹd, bælzəmən keɪm tə hɪm ɪn ə dʒɹim. feɪn əbeɪs hɪmsɛlf ən pɝfɔɹmd ɹaɪts ðət wəd stʃɹaɪk jə dɛf tə hɪɹ ðə hæf ə ðɛm, baɪndɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ivən mɔɹ taɪtli tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. wʌɾ ɪz dʌn ɪn dʒɹimz kən bi mɔɹ deɪnʒɝəs ðən wʌɾ ɪz dʌn əweɪk." ɹænd stɝɾ ət ðə ʃɑɹp, wɔɹnɪŋ lʊk, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt pɔz. "hi wɑz pɹɑməst ɡɹeɪt ɹɪwɔɹdz, paʊɝ oʊvɝ kɪŋdəmz æftɝ bælzəmənz vɪktɝi, ən toʊl ðət wən i ɹɪtɝn tə ɛmənz fild i wɑz tə mɑɹk ðə θɹi hi hæd faʊnd. eɪ hæfmən wəd bi ðɛɹ, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ɪm wɪð tʃɹɑləks. wi noʊ naʊ haʊ ðə tʃɹɑləks keɪm tə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ðəɹ mʌst əv bɪn ən oʊɡiɝ ɡɹoʊv ən ə weɪɡeɪɾ ət meɪnɛðɝən."

Moiraine did not allow Mat to interrupt her. She raised her voice enough to be heard over him. "When Fain returned to Lugard, Ba'alzamon came to him in a dream. Fain abased himself and performed rites that would strike you deaf to hear the half of them, binding himself even more tightly to the Dark One. What is done in dreams can be more dangerous than what is done awake." Rand stirred at the sharp, warning look, but she did not pause. "He was promised great rewards, power over kingdoms after Ba'alzamon's victory, and told that when he returned to Emond's Field he was to mark the three he had found. A Halfman would be there, waiting for him with Trollocs. We know now how the Trollocs came to the Two Rivers. There must have been an Ogier grove and a Waygate at Manetheren."

"ðə moʊs bjuɾəfəl ʌv ɔl," lɔɪəl sɛd, "ɪksɛp fəɹ tɑɹ vəlɑn." hi hæd bɪn lɪsnɪŋ əz ɪntɛnli əz ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls. "meɪnɛðɝən ɪz ɹɪmɛmbɝd fɑnli baɪ ði oʊɡiɝ." eɪɡəlmɝ fɔɹm ðə neɪm saɪlənli, hɪz aɪbɹaʊz ɹeɪzd ɪn wʌndɝ. meɪnɛðɝən.

"The most beautiful of all," Loial said, "except for Tar Valon." He had been listening as intently as everyone else. "Manetheren is remembered fondly by the Ogier." Agelmar formed the name silently, his eyebrows raised in wonder. Manetheren.

"lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "aɪ wɪl tɛl jə haʊ tə faɪn ðə weɪɡeɪɾ ə mæfəl dɑɾɝɑnɛl. ɪt mʌs bi wɔld ʌp ən ə ɡɑɹd sɛt, ən nʌn əlaʊd nɪɹ. ðə hæfmən əv nɑt lɝn ɔl ə ðə weɪz jɛt, bʌt ðət weɪɡeɪɾ ɪz tə ðə saʊθ ən oʊnli aʊɝz fɹəm fæl dæɹə."

"Lord Agelmar," Moiraine said, "I will tell you how to find the Waygate of Mafal Dadaranell. It must be walled up and a guard set, and none allowed near. The Halfmen have not learned all of the Ways yet, but that Waygate is to the south and only hours from Fal Dara."

ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə ɡeɪv hɪmsɛlf ə ʃeɪk, əz ɪf i wɝ kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ə tʃɹæns. "saʊθ? pis! wi doʊnt nid ðæt, ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn ʌs. ɪt ʃæl bi dʌn."

The Lord of Fal Dara gave himself a shake, as if he were coming out of a trance. "South? Peace! We don't need that, the Light shine on us. It shall be done."

"dɪd feɪn fɑloʊ əs θɹu ðə weɪz?" pɛɹɪn æskt. "hi mʌst əv dʌn."

"Did Fain follow us through the Ways?" Perrin asked. "He must have done."

mɔɪɹeɪn nɑɾəd. "feɪn wəd fɑloʊ jə θɹi ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪv, kəz i mʌst. wən ðə mɹdʒɹɑl feɪld əɾ ɛmənz fild, ɪt bɹɔt feɪn wɪð ðə tʃɹɑləks ɑn əɹ tʃɹeɪl. ðə feɪd wəd nɑt lɛt feɪn ɹaɪd wɪð hɪm; ɔlðoʊ hi θɔɾ i ʃəɾ əv ðə bɛs hɔɹs ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz ən ɹaɪɾ ət ðə hɛɾ ə ðə bænd, ðə mɹdʒɹɑl fɔɹst ɪm tə ɹʌn wɪð ðə tʃɹɑləks, ən ðə tʃɹɑləks tə kæɹi hɪm wən ɪz fit ɡeɪv aʊt. ðeɪ tɔk soʊ ðəɾ i kəɾ ʌndɝstænd, ɑɹɡjuɪŋ əbaʊt ðə bɛst weɪ tə kʊk ɪm wən ɪz jusfəlnəs wɑz dʌn. feɪn kleɪmz i tɝn əɡɛns ðə dɑɹk wʌn bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə tɛɹən. bʌt səmtaɪmz ɪz ɡɹid fəɹ ɪz pɹɑməst ɹɪwɔɹdz sips ɪndə ði oʊpən.

Moiraine nodded. "Fain would follow you three into the grave, because he must. When the Myrddraal failed at Emond's Field, it brought Fain with the Trollocs on our trail. The Fade would not let Fain ride with him; although he thought he should have the best horse in the Two Rivers and ride at the head of the band, the Myrddraal forced him to run with the Trollocs, and the Trollocs to carry him when his feet gave out. They talked so that he could understand, arguing about the best way to cook him when his usefulness was done. Fain claims he turned against the Dark One before they reached the Taren. But sometimes his greed for his promised rewards seeps into the open.

"wɛn wi hæɾ ɪskeɪpt əkɹɔs ðə tɛɹən ðə mɹdʒɹɑl tʊk ðə tʃɹɑləks bæk tə ðə kloʊsəst weɪɡeɪt, ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst, ən sɛn feɪn əkɹɔs əloʊn. hi θɔɾ i wɑz fɹi ðɛn, bʌt bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt bɛɹlən ənʌðɝ feɪd faʊn hɪm, ən ðət wʌn wɑz nɑt soʊ kaɪnd. ɪt meɪɾ ɪm slip dʌbəld ʌp ɑn hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə tʃɹɑlɑk kɛɾəl ət naɪt, tə ɹimaɪn ɪm ə ðə pɹaɪs ə feɪljɝ. ðət wʌn juzd ɪm əz fɑɹ əz ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. baɪ ðən feɪn wɑz wɪlɪŋ tə ɡɪv ðə mɹdʒɹɑl ɪz mʌðɝ ɪf ɪt wəd fɹi hɪm, bʌt ðə dɑɹk wʌn nɛvɝ wɪlɪŋli lusənz ə hoʊl hiz ɡeɪnd.

"When we had escaped across the Taren the Myrddraal took the Trollocs back to the closest Waygate, in the Mountains of Mist, and sent Fain across alone. He thought he was free then, but before he reached Baerlon another Fade found him, and that one was not so kind. It made him sleep doubled up on himself in a Trolloc kettle at night, to remind him of the price of failure. That one used him as far as Shadar Logoth. By then Fain was willing to give the Myrddraal his mother if it would free him, but the Dark One never willingly loosens a hold he has gained.

"wʌɾ aɪ dɪd ðɛɹ, sɛndɪŋ ən ɪluʒən ʌv əɹ tʃɹæks ən smɛl ɔf təwɔɹd ðə maʊntənz, ful ðə mɹdʒɹɑl, bʌt nɑt feɪn. ðə hæfmən dɪd nɑt bɪliv hɪm; æftɝwɝd, ðeɪ dʒɹæɡd ɪm bɪhaɪn əm ɑn ə liʃ. oʊnli wən wi sim tə kip ɔlweɪz dʒʌst əhɛd, noʊ mæɾɝ haʊ hɑɹd ðeɪ pɹɛst, dɪd səm bɪɡɪn tə kɹɛɾət hɪm. ðoʊz wɝ ðə fɔɹ u ɹɪtɝn tə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. feɪn kleɪmz ɪt wɑz bælzəmən hɪmsɛlf u dʒɹoʊv ðə mɹdʒɹɑl."

"What I did there, sending an illusion of our tracks and smell off toward the mountains, fooled the Myrddraal, but not Fain. The Halfmen did not believe him; afterward, they dragged him behind them on a leash. Only when we seemed to keep always just ahead, no matter how hard they pressed, did some begin to credit him. Those were the four who returned to Shadar Logoth. Fain claims it was Ba'alzamon himself who drove the Myrddraal."

eɪɡəlmɝ ʃʊk ɪz hɛd kəntɛmptʃwəsli. "ðə dɑɹk wʌn? pæ! ðə mænz laɪɪŋ əɹ mæd. ɪf hɑɹtsbeɪn wɝ lus, wiɾ ɔl ʌv əs bi dɛd baɪ naʊ, əɹ wɝs."

Agelmar shook his head contemptuously. "The Dark One? Pah! The man's lying or mad. If Heartsbane were loose, we'd all of us be dead by now, or worse."

"feɪn spoʊk ðə tʃɹuθ əz i sɔ ɪt," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "hi kəd nɑt laɪ tə mi, ðoʊ hi hɪd mʌtʃ. hɪz wɝdz. 'bælzəmən əpɪɹd laɪk ə flɪkɝɪŋ kændəl fleɪm, vænɪʃɪŋ ən ɹiəpɪɹɪŋ, nɛvɝ ɪn ðə seɪm pleɪs twaɪs. hɪz aɪz sɪɹd ðə mɹdʒɹɑl, ən ðə faɪɝz ə hɪz maʊθ skaʊɝdʒd ʌs.' "

"Fain spoke the truth as he saw it," Moiraine said. "He could not lie to me, though he hid much. His words. 'Ba'alzamon appeared like a flickering candle flame, vanishing and reappearing, never in the same place twice. His eyes seared the Myrddraal, and the fires of his mouth scourged us.' "

"sʌmθɪŋ," læn sɛd, "dʒɹoʊv fɔɹ feɪdz tə wɛɹ ðeɪ fɪɹd tə ɡoʊ - ə pleɪs ðeɪ fɪɹ ɔlmoʊst əz mʌtʃ əz ðeɪ fɪɹ ðə ɹæθ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn."

"Something," Lan said, "drove four Fades to where they feared to go - a place they fear almost as much as they fear the wrath of the Dark One."

eɪɡəlmɝ ɡɹʌntɪɾ əz ɪf i hæd bɪn kɪkt; hi lʊk sɪk.

Agelmar grunted as if he had been kicked; he looked sick.

"ɪt wɑz ivəl əɡɛnst ivəl ɪn ðə ɹuənz ə ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ," mɔɪɹeɪn kəntɪnjud, "faʊl faɪɾɪŋ vaɪl. wən feɪn spoʊk ʌv ɪt, hɪz tiθ tʃæɾɝd ən i wɪmpɝd. mɛni tʃɹɑləks wɝ sleɪn, kənsum baɪ mɑʃəɾɝ ən ʌðɝ θɪŋz, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ðət hɛl feɪnz liʃ. hi flɛd ðə sɪɾi əz ɪf ɪt wɝ ðə pɪɾ ə dum, ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl.

"It was evil against evil in the ruins of Shadar Logoth," Moiraine continued, "foul fighting vile. When Fain spoke of it, his teeth chattered and he whimpered. Many Trollocs were slain, consumed by Mashadar and other things, including the Trolloc that held Fain's leash. He fled the city as if it were the Pit of Doom, at Shayol Ghul.

"feɪn bɪlivd i wɑz fɹi ət læst. hi ɪntɛndəd tə ɹʌn əntɪl bælzəmən kəd nɛvɝ faɪn ɪm əɡɛn, tə ði ɛnz ə ði ɝθ ɪf nɛsəsɛɹi. ɪmædʒən ɪz hɔɹɝ wən i dɪskʌvɝd ðət ðə kəmpʌlʃən tə hʌn dɪd nɑt lɛsən. ɪnstɛd, ɪt ɡɹu stʃɹɔŋɝ ən ʃɑɹpɝ wɪð ɛvɹi deɪ ðət pæst. hi kəd nɑɾ it, ɪksɛpt wʌɾ i kəd skævənʒ waɪl i hʌntəd jə - biɾəlz ən lɪzɝdz snætʃt waɪl i ɹæn, hæf-ɹɑɾən ɹɛfjus dʌɡ fɹəm mɪɾən hips ɪn ðə dɑɹk ə naɪt - nɔɹ kəɾ i stɑp əntɪl ɪɡzɔstʃən kəlæpst ɪm laɪk ən ɛmpti sæk. ən əz sun əz i hæd stʃɹɛŋkθ tə stæn əɡɛn, hi wɑz dʒɹɪvən ɑn. baɪ ðə taɪm i ɹitʃt keɪɛmlɪn i kəd fil ɪz kwɔɹi ivən wən ɪt wɑz ə maɪl əweɪ. hɪɹ, ɪn ðə sɛlz bɪloʊ, hi wəd səmtaɪmz lʊk ʌp wɪθaʊt ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ. hi wɑz lʊkɪŋ ɪn ðə dɝɛkʃən ə ðɪs ɹum."

"Fain believed he was free at last. He intended to run until Ba'alzamon could never find him again, to the ends of the earth if necessary. Imagine his horror when he discovered that the compulsion to hunt did not lessen. Instead, it grew stronger and sharper with every day that passed. He could not eat, except what he could scavenge while he hunted you - beetles and lizards snatched while he ran, half-rotten refuse dug from midden heaps in the dark of night - nor could he stop until exhaustion collapsed him like an empty sack. And as soon as he had strength to stand again, he was driven on. By the time he reached Caemlyn he could feel his quarry even when it was a mile away. Here, in the cells below, he would sometimes look up without realizing what he was doing. He was looking in the direction of this room."

ɹænd hæɾ ə sʌɾən ɪtʃ bɪtwin ɪz ʃoʊldɝ bleɪdz; ɪt wɑz əz ɪf i kəd fil feɪnz aɪz ɑn ɪm ðɛn, θɹu ði ɪntɝvinɪŋ stoʊn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ noʊɾəst ɪz ənizi ʃɹʌɡ, bʌt ʃi wɛn ɑn ɪmplækəbli.

Rand had a sudden itch between his shoulder blades; it was as if he could feel Fain's eyes on him then, through the intervening stone. The Aes Sedai noticed his uneasy shrug, but she went on implacably.

"ɪf feɪn wɑz hæf mæd baɪ ðə taɪm i ɹitʃt keɪɛmlɪn, hi sæŋk ivən fɝðɝ wən i ɹilaɪz ðəɾ oʊnli tu ʌv ðoʊz i sɔt wɝ ðɛɹ. hi wɑz kəmpɛl tə faɪn ɔl ə ju, bʌɾ i kəd də noʊ ʌðɝ ðən fɑloʊ ðə tu hu wɝ ðɛɹ, iðɝ. hi spoʊk ə skɹimɪŋ wən ðə weɪɡeɪɾ oʊpən ɪn keɪɛmlɪn. ðə nɑlədʒ ə haʊ tə də ɪt wɑz ɪn ɪz maɪnd; hi dʌz nɑt noʊ haʊ ɪt keɪm ðɛɹ; hɪz hænz muvd ə ðɛɹ oʊn əkɔɹd, bɝnɪŋ wɪð ðə faɪɝz ə bælzəmən wən i tʃɹaɪd tə stɑp ðɛm. ði oʊnɝ ə ðə ʃɑp, hu keɪm tə ɪnvɛstəɡeɪt ðə nɔɪz, feɪn mɝɾɝd. nɑt kəz i hæd tə, bʌɾ aʊɾ ʌv ɛnvi ðət ðə mæn kəd wɔk fɹili aʊɾ ə ðə sɛlɝ waɪl ɪz fit kæɹiɾ ɪm ɪnɛksɝəbli ɪndə ðə weɪz."

"If Fain was half mad by the time he reached Caemlyn, he sank even further when he realized that only two of those he sought were there. He was compelled to find all of you, but he could do no other than follow the two who were there, either. He spoke of screaming when the Waygate opened in Caemlyn. The knowledge of how to do it was in his mind; he does not know how it came there; his hands moved of their own accord, burning with the fires of Ba'alzamon when he tried to stop them. The owner of the shop, who came to investigate the noise, Fain murdered. Not because he had to, but out of envy that the man could walk freely out of the cellar while his feet carried him inexorably into the Ways."

"ðɛn feɪn wɑz ðə wʌn jə sɛns fɑloʊɪŋ ʌs," ɛɡwin sɛd. læn nɑɾəd. "haʊ dɪɾ i ɪskeɪp ðə . . . ðə blæk waɪnd?" hɝ vɔɪs ʃʊk; ʃi stɑp tə swɑloʊ. "ɪt wɑz ɹaɪt bɪhaɪn əs ət ðə weɪɡeɪt."

"Then Fain was the one you sensed following us," Egwene said. Lan nodded. "How did he escape the . . . the Black Wind?" Her voice shook; she stopped to swallow. "It was right behind us at the Waygate."

"hi ɪskeɪpt, ən i dɪd nɑt," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ðə blæk wɪn kɑɾ ɪm - ən i kleɪm tə ʌndɝstæn ðə vɔɪsəz. səm ɡɹiɾəd ɪm əz laɪk tə ðɛm; ʌðɝz fɪɹd hɪm. noʊ sunɝ dɪd ðə wɪn ɪnvɛləp feɪn ðən ɪt flɛd."

"He escaped, and he did not," Moiraine said. "The Black Wind caught him - and he claimed to understand the voices. Some greeted him as like to them; others feared him. No sooner did the Wind envelop Fain than it fled."

"ðə laɪt pɹəzɝv ʌs." lɔɪəlz wɪspɝ ɹʌmbəld laɪk ə dʒaɪən bʌmbəlɪbi.

"The Light preserve us." Loial's whisper rumbled like a giant bumblebee.

"pɹeɪ ðəɾ ɪt dʌz," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ðɛɹ ɪz mʌtʃ jɛt hɪɾən əbaʊt pdən feɪn, mʌtʃ aɪ mʌs lɝn. ði ivəl ɡoʊz dipɝ ɪn hɪm, ən stʃɹɔŋɝ, ðən ɪn ɛni mæn aɪ hæv jɛt sin. ɪt meɪbi ðət ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ɪn duɪŋ wʌɾ i dɪd tə feɪn, ɪmpɹɛst səm pɑɹɾ ə hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə mæn, pɝhæps ivən, ənnoʊɪŋ, səm pɑɹɾ ə hɪz ɪntɛnt. wən aɪ mɛnʃən ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld, feɪn klæmpt ɪz dʒɔz ʃʌt, bʌɾ aɪ fɛl sʌmθɪŋ noʊɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðə saɪləns. ɪf oʊnli aɪ hæd ðə taɪm naʊ. bʌt wi kænɑt weɪt."

"Pray that it does," Moiraine said. "There is much yet hidden about Padan Fain, much I must learn. The evil goes deeper in him, and stronger, than in any man I have yet seen. It maybe that the Dark One, in doing what he did to Fain, impressed some part of himself on the man, perhaps even, unknowing, some part of his intent. When I mentioned the Eye of the World, Fain clamped his jaws shut, but I felt something knowing behind the silence. If only I had the time now. But we cannot wait."

"ɪf ðɪs mæn noʊz sʌmθɪŋ," eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd, "aɪ kən ɡɛɾ ɪɾ aʊɾ ə hɪm." hɪz feɪs hɛl noʊ mɝsi fəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz; hɪz vɔɪs pɹɑməs noʊ pɪɾi fəɹ feɪn. "ɪf jə kən lɝn ivən ə pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌt jəl feɪs ɪn ðə blaɪt, ɪts wɝθ ən ɛkstʃɹə deɪ. bæɾəlz əv bɪn lɔs fəɹ nɑt noʊɪŋ wʌt ði ɛnəmi ɪntɛnz."

"If this man knows something," Agelmar said, "I can get it out of him." His face held no mercy for Darkfriends; his voice promised no pity for Fain. "If you can learn even a part of what you will face in the Blight, it's worth an extra day. Battles have been lost for not knowing what the enemy intends."

mɔɪɹeɪn saɪɾ ən ʃʊk əɹ hɛd ɹufəli. "maɪ lɔɹd, ɪf wi dɪd nɑt niɾ ət list wʌn ɡʊd naɪts slip bɪfɔɹ feɪsɪŋ ðə blaɪt, aɪ wəd ɹaɪd wɪðɪn ði aʊɝ, ðoʊ ɪt mɛn ðə ɹɪsk ə miɾɪŋ ə tʃɹɑlɑk ɹeɪɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk. kənsɪɾɝ wʌɾ aɪ dɪd lɝn fɹəm feɪn. θɹi jɪɹz əɡoʊ ðə dɑɹk wʌn hæd tə hæv feɪn bɹɔt tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl tə tʌtʃ hɪm, dɪspaɪt ðə fæk ðət feɪn ɪz ə dɑɹkfɹɛn dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə hɪz mɛɹoʊ. wʌn jɪɹ əɡoʊ, ðə dɑɹk wʌn kəd kəmæn feɪn, ðə dɑɹkfɹɛnd, θɹu hɪz dʒɹimz. ðɪs jɪɹ, bælzəmən wɔks ɪn ðə dʒɹimz ə ðoʊz u lɪv ɪn ðə laɪt, ən æktʃəli  əpɪɹz, ɪf wɪð dɪfəkəlti, ət ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ. nɑɾ ɪn ɪz oʊn bɑɾi, ʌv kɔɹs, bʌɾ ivən ə pɹədʒɛkʃən ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz maɪnd, ivən ə pɹədʒɛkʃən ðət flɪkɝz ən kænɑt hoʊld, ɪz mɔɹ dɛθli deɪnʒɝəs tə ðə wɝl ðən ɔl ðə tʃɹɑlɑk hɔɹdz kəmbaɪnd. ðə silz ɑn ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl ɑɹ wikənɪŋ dɛspɝətli, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ taɪm."

Moiraine sighed and shook her head ruefully. "My lord, if we did not need at least one good night's sleep before facing the Blight, I would ride within the hour, though it meant the risk of meeting a Trolloc raid in the dark. Consider what I did learn from Fain. Three years ago the Dark One had to have Fain brought to Shayol Ghul to touch him, despite the fact that Fain is a Darkfriend dedicated to his marrow. One year ago, the Dark One could command Fain, the Darkfriend, through his dreams. This year, Ba'alzamon walks in the dreams of those who live in the Light, and actually appears, if with difficulty, at Shadar Logoth. Not in his own body, of course, but even a projection of the Dark One's mind, even a projection that flickers and cannot hold, is more deathly dangerous to the world than all the Trolloc hordes combined. The seals on Shayol Ghul are weakening desperately, Lord Agelmar. There is no time."

eɪɡəlmɝ baʊɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn ækwiɛsəns, bʌt wən i ɹeɪzd ɪɾ əɡɛn ðəɹ wɑz stɪl ə stʌbɝn sɛt tə hɪz maʊθ. "ɛɛs sədaɪ, aɪ kən æksɛp ðət wən aɪ lɛd ðə lænsɪz tə tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp wɪl bi noʊ mɔɹ ðən ə daɪvɝʒən, əɹ ə skɝmɪʃ ɑn ði aʊtskɝts ə ðə ɹil bæɾəl. duɾi teɪks mɛn wɛɹ ɪɾəl əz ʃʊɹli əz dʌz ðə pæɾɝn, ən niðɝ pɹɑməsəz ðət wʌt wi də wɪl əv ɡɹeɪtnəs. bʌɾ əɹ skɝmɪʃ wɪl bi jusləs, ivən ʃəd wi wɪn, ɪf jə luz ðə bæɾəl. ɪf jə seɪ jəɹ pɑɹɾi mʌs bi smɔl, aɪ seɪ wɛl ən ɡʊd, bʌɾ aɪ bɛɡ jə tə meɪk ɛvɹi ɛfɝt tə si ðət jə kən wɪn. liv ðiz jʌŋ mɛn hɪɹ, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ swɛɹ tə jə ðəɾ aɪ kən faɪn θɹi ɪkspɪɹiəns mɛn wɪð noʊ θɔɾ ʌv ɡlɔɹi ɪn ðɛɹ hɛdz tə ɹipleɪs ðɛm, ɡʊd sɔɝdzmɪn u ɑɹ ɔlmoʊst əz hændi ɪn ðə blaɪɾ əz læn. lemi ɹaɪd tə ðə ɡæp noʊɪŋ ðəɾ aɪ hæv dʌn wʌɾ aɪ kən tə hɛlp jə bi vɪktɔɹiəs."

Agelmar bowed his head in acquiescence, but when he raised it again there was still a stubborn set to his mouth. "Aes Sedai, I can accept that when I lead the lances to Tarwin's Gap we will be no more than a diversion, or a skirmish on the outskirts of the real battle. Duty takes men where it will as surely as does the Pattern, and neither promises that what we do will have greatness. But our skirmish will be useless, even should we win, if you lose the battle. If you say your party must be small, I say well and good, but I beg you to make every effort to see that you can win. Leave these young men here, Aes Sedai. I swear to you that I can find three experienced men with no thought of glory in their heads to replace them, good swordsmen who are almost as handy in the Blight as Lan. Let me ride to the Gap knowing that I have done what I can to help you be victorious."

"aɪ mʌs teɪk əm ən noʊ ʌðɝz, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd dʒɛnli. "ðeɪ ɑɹ ðə wʌnz u wɪl faɪt ðə bæɾəl ət ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld."

"I must take them and no others, Lord Agelmar," Moiraine said gently. "They are the ones who will fight the battle at the Eye of the World."

eɪɡəlmɝz dʒɔ dʒɹɑpt, ən i stɛɹɾ ət ɹænd ən mæt ən pɛɹɪn. sʌɾənli ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə tʊk ə stɛp bæk, hɪz hænd ɡɹoʊpɪŋ ʌnkɑnʃəsli fəɹ ðə sɔɹɾ i nɛvɝ wɔɹ ɪnsaɪd ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs. "ðeɪ ɑɹənt. . . . jə ɑɹ nɑt ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ, bʌt ʃʊɹli nɑɾ ivən jə wʊd. . . ." sʌɾən swɛt ɡlɪsən ɑn ɪz ʃeɪvən hɛd.

Agelmar's jaw dropped, and he stared at Rand and Mat and Perrin. Suddenly the Lord of Fal Dara took a step back, his hand groping unconsciously for the sword he never wore inside the fortress. "They aren't. . . . You are not Red Ajah, Moiraine Sedai, but surely not even you would. . . ." Sudden sweat glistened on his shaven head.

"ðeɪ ɑɹ tɑvɝən," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd suðɪŋli. "ðə pæɾɝn wivz ɪtsɛlf ɝaʊn ðɛm. ɔlɹɛɾi ðə dɑɹk wʌn əz tʃɹaɪd tə kɪl itʃ ə ðɛm mɔɹ ðən wʌns. θɹi tɑvɝən ɪn wʌn pleɪs ɑɹ ɪnʌf tə tʃeɪnʒ ðə laɪf ɝaʊn əm əz ʃʊɹli əz ə wɝl pul tʃeɪnʒəz ðə pæθ ʌv ə stʃɹɔ. wən ðə pleɪs ɪz ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld, ðə pæɾɝn maɪt wiv ivən ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz ɪndə ɪtsɛlf, ən meɪk ɪm hɑɹmləs əɡɛn."

"They are ta'veren," Moiraine said soothingly. "The Pattern weaves itself around them. Already the Dark One has tried to kill each of them more than once. Three ta'veren in one place are enough to change the life around them as surely as a whirl pool changes the path of a straw. When the place is the Eye of the World, the Pattern might weave even the Father of Lies into itself, and make him harmless again."

eɪɡəlmɝ stɑp tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə faɪn ɪz sɔɹd, bʌɾ i stɪl lʊkt ət ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz daʊtfəli. "mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ, ɪf jə seɪ ðeɪ ɑɹ, ðən ðeɪ ɑɹ, bʌɾ aɪ kænɑt si ɪt. fɑɹmbɔɪz. ɑɹ jə sɝɾən, ɛɛs sədaɪ?"

Agelmar stopped trying to find his sword, but he still looked at Rand and the others doubtfully. "Moiraine Sedai, if you say they are, then they are, but I cannot see it. Farmboys. Are you certain, Aes Sedai?"

"ði oʊl blʌd," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "splɪɾ aʊt laɪk ə ɹɪvɝ bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪndə ə θaʊzən taɪmz ə θaʊzən stʃɹimz, bʌt səmtaɪmz stʃɹimz dʒɔɪn təɡɛðɝ tə meɪk ə ɹɪvɝ əɡɛn. ði oʊl blʌɾ ə meɪnɛðɝən ɪz stʃɹɔŋ ən pjʊɹ ɪn ɔlmoʊst ɔl ðiz jʌŋ mɛn. kən jə daʊt ðə stʃɹɛŋkθ ə meɪnɛðɝənz blʌd, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ?"

"The old blood," Moiraine said, "split out like a river breaking into a thousand times a thousand streams, but sometimes streams join together to make a river again. The old blood of Manetheren is strong and pure in almost all these young men. Can you doubt the strength of Manetheren's blood, Lord Agelmar?"

ɹænd ɡlænst saɪdweɪz ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ɔlmoʊst ɔl. hi ɹɪskt ə lʊk ət nɪneɪiv; ʃi hæd tɝn bæk tə wɑtʃ əz wɛl əz lɪsən, ðoʊ ʃi stɪl əvɔɪɾəd lʊkɪŋ ət læn. hi kɑt ðə wɪzdəmz aɪ. ʃi ʃʊk əɹ hɛd; ʃi hæd nɑt toʊl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ðəɾ i wɑz nɑt tu ɹɪvɝz bɔɹn. wʌt dʌz mɔɪɹeɪn noʊ?

Rand glanced sideways at the Aes Sedai. Almost all. He risked a look at Nynaeve; she had turned back to watch as well as listen, though she still avoided looking at Lan. He caught the Wisdom's eye. She shook her head; she had not told the Aes Sedai that he was not Two Rivers born. What does Moiraine know?

"meɪnɛðɝən," eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd sloʊli, nɑɾɪŋ. "aɪ wəd nɑt daʊt ðət blʌd." ðɛn, mɔɹ kwɪkli, "ðə wil bɹɪŋz stʃɹeɪnʒ taɪmz. fɑɹmbɔɪz kæɹi ði ɑnɝ ə meɪnɛðɝən ɪndə ðə blaɪt, jɛɾ ɪf ɛni blʌd kən stʃɹaɪk ə fɛl bloʊ ət ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ɪt wəd bi ðə blʌɾ ə meɪnɛðɝən. ɪt ʃæl bi dʌn əz jə wɪʃ, ɛɛs sədaɪ."

"Manetheren," Agelmar said slowly, nodding. "I would not doubt that blood." Then, more quickly, "The Wheel brings strange times. Farmboys carry the honor of Manetheren into the Blight, yet if any blood can strike a fell blow at the Dark One, it would be the blood of Manetheren. It shall be done as you wish, Aes Sedai."

"ðɛn lɛɾ əs ɡoʊ tə əɹ ɹumz," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "wi mʌs liv wɪð ðə sʌn, fəɹ taɪm ɡɹoʊz ʃɔɹt. ðə jʌŋ mɛn mʌst slip kloʊs tə mi. taɪm ɪz tu ʃɔɹt bɪfɔɹ ðə bæɾəl tə əlaʊ ðə dɑɹk wʌn ənʌðɝ stʃɹaɪk ət ðɛm. tu ʃɔɹt."

"Then let us go to our rooms," Moiraine said. "We must leave with the sun, for time grows short. The young men must sleep close to me. Time is too short before the battle to allow the Dark One another strike at them. Too short."

ɹænd fɛlt əɹ aɪz ɑn hɪm, stʌɾiɪŋ ɪm ən ɪz fɹɛnz, weɪɪŋ ðɛɹ stʃɹɛŋkθ, ən i ʃɪvɝd. tu ʃɔɹt.

Rand felt her eyes on him, studying him and his friends, weighing their strength, and he shivered. Too short.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾieɪt


CHAPTER 48

ðə blaɪt


The Blight

ðə wɪnd wɪp lænz kloʊk, səmtaɪmz meɪkɪŋ ɪm hɑɹd tə si ivən ɪn ðə sʌnlaɪt, ən ɪŋtʃɹ ən ðə hʌnʒɹəd lænsɪz lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ hæd sɛn tə ɛskɔɹɾ əm tə ðə bɔɹɾɝ, ɪn keɪs ðeɪ mɛɾ ə tʃɹɑlɑk ɹeɪd, meɪɾ ə bɹeɪv dɪspleɪ ɪn dʌbəl kɑləm wɪð ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ ən ðɛɹ ɹɛd pɛnəns ən ðɛɹ stil-klæd hɔɹsəz lɛd baɪ ɪŋtʃɹz ɡɹeɪ aʊl bænɝ. ðeɪ wɝ izəli əz ɡɹæn əz ə hʌnʒɹəd ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹdz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðə taʊɝz dʒʌst ɪn saɪɾ əhɛɾ ə ðɛm ðət ɹænd stʌɾid. hi hæd hæɾ ɔl mɔɹnɪŋ tə wɑtʃ ðə ʃaɪnɝən lænsɪz.

The wind whipped Lan's cloak, sometimes making him hard to see even in the sunlight, and Ingtar and the hundred lances Lord Agelmar had sent to escort them to the Border, in case they met a Trolloc raid, made a brave display in double column with their armor and their red pennants and their steel-clad horses led by Ingtar's Gray Owl banner. They were easily as grand as a hundred of the Queen's Guards, but it was the towers just in sight ahead of them that Rand studied. He had had all morning to watch the Shienaran lances.

itʃ taʊɝ stʊd tɔl ən sɑləɾ ətɑp ə hɪl, hæf ə maɪl fɹəm ɪts neɪbɝ. ist ən wɛst ʌðɝz ɹoʊz, ən mɔɹ bɪɑn ðoʊz. ə bɹɔd, wɔld ɹæmp spaɪɹəld ɝaʊn itʃ stoʊn ʃæft, waɪndɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊn baɪ ðə taɪm ɪt ɹitʃt ðə hɛvi ɡeɪts hæfweɪ tə ðə kɹɛnɛleɪɾɪd tɑp. ə sɔɹɾi fɹəm ðə ɡɛɹɪsən wəd bi pɹətɛktəd baɪ ðə wɔl əntɪl ɪt ɹitʃt ðə ɡɹaʊnd, bʌɾ ɛnəmiz stʃɹaɪvɪŋ tə ɹitʃ ðə ɡeɪt wəd klaɪm ʌndɝ ə heɪl ʌv æɹoʊz ən stoʊnz ən hɑɾ ɔɪl fɹəm ðə bɪɡ kɛɾəlz pɔɪzd ɑn ði aʊtwɝd flɛɹɪŋ ɹæmpɑɹts əbʌv. ə lɑɹdʒ stil mɪɹɝ, kɛɹfəli tɝn daʊn, əweɪ fɹəm ðə sʌn, naʊ, ɡlɪɾɝd ətɑp itʃ taʊɝ bɪloʊ ðə haɪ aɪɝn kʌp wɛɹ sɪɡnəl faɪɝz kəd bi lɪt wən ðə sʌn dɪd nɑt ʃaɪn. ðə sɪɡnəl wəd bi flæʃt, tə taʊɝz fɝðɝ fɹəm ðə bɔɹɾɝ, ən baɪ ðoʊz tə stɪl ʌðɝz, ən soʊ ɹileɪd tə ðə hɑɹtlæn fɔɹtʃɹəsəz, fɹəm wɛɹ ðə lænsɪz wəd ɹaɪd tə tɝn bæk ðə ɹeɪd. wɝ taɪmz nɔɹməl, ðeɪ wʊd.

Each tower stood tall and solid atop a hill, half a mile from its neighbor. East and west others rose, and more beyond those. A broad, walled ramp spiraled around each stone shaft, winding all the way around by the time it reached the heavy gates halfway to the crenellated top. A sortie from the garrison would be protected by the wall until it reached the ground, but enemies striving to reach the gate would climb under a hail of arrows and stones and hot oil from the big kettles poised on the outward flaring ramparts above. A large steel mirror, carefully turned down, away from the sun, now, glittered atop each tower below the high iron cup where signal fires could be lit when the sun did not shine. The signal would be flashed, to towers further from the Border, and by those to still others, and so relayed to the heartland fortresses, from where the lances would ride to turn back the raid. Were times normal, they would.

fɹəm ðə tu nɪɹəs taʊɝ tɑps mɛn wɑtʃt əm əpɹoʊtʃ. dʒʌst ə fju mɛn ɑn itʃ, piɹɪŋ kjʊɹiəsli θɹu ðə kɹɛnəlz. ɪn ðə bɛst ə taɪmz ðə taʊɝz wɝ oʊnli mæn ɪnʌf fəɹ sɛlf-dɪfɛns, dɪpɛndɪŋ mɔɹ ɑn stoʊn wɔlz ðən stʃɹɔŋ ɑɹmz tə sɝvaɪv, bʌɾ ɛvɹi mæn u kəd bi spɛɹd, ən mɔɹ, wɑz ɹaɪɾɪŋ tə tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp. ðə fɔl ə ðə taʊɝz wəd nɑt mæɾɝ ɪf ðə lænsɪz feɪl tə hoʊl ðə ɡæp.

From the two nearest tower tops men watched them approach. Just a few men on each, peering curiously through the crenels. In the best of times the towers were only manned enough for self-defense, depending more on stone walls than strong arms to survive, but every man who could be spared, and more, was riding to Tarwin's Gap. The fall of the towers would not matter if the lances failed to hold the Gap.

ɹænd ʃɪvɝɾ əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd bɪtwin ðə taʊɝz. ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊst əz ɪf i hæd ɹɪɾən θɹu ə wɔl ə koʊldɝ ɛɹ. ðɪs wɑz ðə bɔɹɾɝ. ðə læn bɪɑn lʊk noʊ dɪfɹən fɹəm ʃaɪnɝ, bʌɾ aʊt ðɛɹ, sʌmwɛɹ bɪɑn ðə lifləs tʃɹiz, wɑz ðə blaɪt.

Rand shivered as they rode between the towers. It was almost as if he had ridden through a wall of colder air. This was the Border. The land beyond looked no different from Shienar, but out there, somewhere beyond the leafless trees, was the Blight.

ɪŋtʃɹ lɪftəɾ ə stil fɪs tə hɔl ðə lænsɪz ʃɔɹɾ ʌv ə pleɪn stoʊn poʊst ɪn saɪɾ ə ðə taʊɝz. ə bɔɹɾɝpoʊst, mɑɹkɪŋ ðə baʊndɝi bɪtwin ʃaɪnɝ ən wʌt wʌns wɑz mɔlkiɝ. "jɔɹ pɑɹɾən, mɔɪɹeɪn ɛɛs sədaɪ. pɑɹɾən, daɪ ʃæn. pɑɹɾən, bɪldɝ. lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ kəmændəd mi tə ɡoʊ noʊ fɝðɝ." hi saʊndəɾ ənhæpi əbaʊɾ ɪt, dɪsɡɹʌntəld ət laɪf ɪn dʒɛnɝəl.

Ingtar lifted a steel fist to halt the lances short of a plain stone post in sight of the towers. A borderpost, marking the boundary between Shienar and what once was Malkier. "Your pardon, Moiraine Aes Sedai. Pardon, Dai Shan. Pardon, Builder. Lord Agelmar commanded me to go no further." He sounded unhappy about it, disgruntled at life in general.

"ðæɾ ɪz əz wi plænd, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ ən aɪ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd.

"That is as we planned, Lord Agelmar and I," Moiraine said.

ɪŋtʃɹ ɡɹʌntɪd saʊɝli. "pɑɹɾən, ɛɛs sədaɪ," hi əpɑlədʒaɪzd, nɑt saʊndɪŋ əz ɪf i mɛn ɪt. "tə ɛskɔɹt jə hɪɹ minz wi meɪ nɑt ɹitʃ ðə ɡæp bɪfɔɹ ðə faɪɾɪŋ ɪz dʌn. aɪm ɹɑbd ə ðə tʃæns tə stænd wɪð ðə ɹɛst, ən ət ðə seɪm taɪm aɪm kəmændəd nɑt tə ɹaɪd wʌn stɛp bɪɑn ðə bɔɹɾɝpoʊst, əz ɪf aɪ hæd nɛvɝ bɪfɔɹ bɪn ɪn ðə blaɪt. ən maɪ lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ wɪl nɑt tɛl mi waɪ." bɪhaɪn ðə bɑɹz ə hɪz feɪs-ɡɑɹd, hɪz aɪz tɝn ðə læst wɝɾ ɪndə ə kwɛstʃən tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. hi skɔɹn tə lʊk ət ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz; hi hæd lɝn ðeɪ wəɾ əkʌmpəni læn ɪndə ðə blaɪt.

Ingtar grunted sourly. "Pardon, Aes Sedai," he apologized, not sounding as if he meant it. "To escort you here means we may not reach the Gap before the fighting is done. I am robbed of the chance to stand with the rest, and at the same time I am commanded not to ride one step beyond the borderpost, as if I had never before been in the Blight. And My Lord Agelmar will not tell me why." Behind the bars of his face-guard, his eyes turned the last word into a question to the Aes Sedai. He scorned to look at Rand and the others; he had learned they would accompany Lan into the Blight.

"hi kən əv maɪ pleɪs," mæt mʌɾɝd tə ɹænd. læn ɡeɪv əm boʊθ ə ʃɑɹp lʊk. mæt dʒɹɑpt ɪz aɪz, hɪz feɪs tɝnɪŋ ɹɛd.

"He can have my place," Mat muttered to Rand. Lan gave them both a sharp look. Mat dropped his eyes, his face turning red.

"itʃ ʌv əs əz ɪz pɑɹɾ ɪn ðə pæɾɝn, ɪŋtʃɹ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd fɝmli. "fɹʌm hɪɹ wi mʌs θɹɛɾ aʊɝz əloʊn."

"Each of us has his part in the Pattern, Ingtar," Moiraine said firmly. "From here we must thread ours alone."

ɪŋtʃɹz baʊ wɑz stɪfɝ ðən ɪz ɑɹmɝ meɪɾ ɪt. "æz jə wɪʃ ɪt, ɛɛs sədaɪ. aɪ mʌs liv ju, naʊ, ən ɹaɪd hɑɹɾ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə ɹitʃ tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp. ət list əl bi . . . əlaʊd . . . tə feɪs tʃɹɑləks ðɛɹ."

Ingtar's bow was stiffer than his armor made it. "As you wish it, Aes Sedai. I must leave you, now, and ride hard in order to reach Tarwin's Gap. At least I will be . . . allowed . . . to face Trollocs there."

"ɑɹ jə tʃɹuli ðəɾ iɡɝ?" nɪneɪiv æskt. "tə faɪt tʃɹɑləks?"

"Are you truly that eager?" Nynaeve asked. "To fight Trollocs?"

ɪŋtʃɹ ɡeɪv əɹ ə pʌzəld lʊk, ðən ɡlænst ət læn əz ɪf ðə wɔɹɾɝ maɪɾ ɪkspleɪn. "ðæɾ ɪz wʌɾ aɪ du, leɪɾi," hi sɛd sloʊli. "ðæɾ ɪz waɪ aɪ æm." hi ɹeɪzd ə ɡɔntələɾəd hæn tə læn, oʊpən pɑm təwɔɹd ðə wɔɹɾɝ. "sɝævaɪ nɪntoʊ mænʃimə teɪʃaɪt, daɪ ʃæn. pis feɪvɝ jəɹ sɔɹd." pʊlɪŋ ɪz hɔɹs ɝaʊnd, ɪŋtʃɹ ɹoʊɾ ist wɪð ɪz bænɝmən ən ɪz hʌnʒɹəd lænsɪz. ðeɪ wɛn əɾ ə wɔk, bʌɾ ə stɛɾi peɪs, əz fæst əz ɑɹmɝd hɔɹsəz kəd mænədʒ wɪð ə fɑɹ dɪstəns jɛt tə ɡoʊ.

Ingtar gave her a puzzled look, then glanced at Lan as if the Warder might explain. "That is what I do, Lady," he said slowly. "That is why I am." He raised a gauntleted hand to Lan, open palm toward the warder. "Suravye ninto manshima taishite, Dai Shan. Peace favor your sword." Pulling his horse around, Ingtar rode east with his bannerman and his hundred lances. They went at a walk, but a steady pace, as fast as armored horses could manage with a far distance yet to go.

"wʌɾ ə stʃɹeɪnʒ θɪŋ tə seɪ," ɛɡwin sɛd. "waɪ də ðeɪ juz ɪt laɪk ðæt? pis."

"What a strange thing to say," Egwene said. "Why do they use it like that? Peace."

"wɛn juv nɛvɝ noʊn ə θɪŋ ɪksɛp tə dʒɹim," læn ɹɪplaɪd, hilɪŋ mændɑɹb fɔɹwɝd, "ɪt bɪkʌmz mɔɹ ðən ə tælɪsmən."

"When you have never known a thing except to dream," Lan replied, heeling Mandarb forward, "it becomes more than a talisman."

əz ɹænd fɑloʊd ðə wɔɹɾɝ pæs ðə stoʊn bɔɹɾɝpoʊst, hi tɝn ɪn ɪz sæɾəl tə lʊk bæk, wɑtʃɪŋ ɪŋtʃɹ ən ðə lænsɪz dɪsəpɪɹ bɪhaɪn bæɹən tʃɹiz, ən ðə bɔɹɾɝpoʊst vænɪʃ, ən læst ʌv ɔl ðə taʊɝz ɑn ðɛɹ hɪltɑps, lʊkɪŋ oʊvɝ ðə tʃɹiz. ɔl tu sun ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn, ɹaɪɾɪŋ nɔɹθ ʌndɝ ðə lifləs kænəpi ʌv ðə fɔɹəst. ɹænd sæŋk ɪndə wɑtʃfəl saɪləns, ən fəɹ wʌns ivən mæt hæd nʌθɪŋ tə seɪ.

As Rand followed the Warder past the stone borderpost, he turned in his saddle to look back, watching Ingtar and the lances disappear behind barren trees, and the borderpost vanish, and last of all the towers on their hilltops, looking over the trees. All too soon they were alone, riding north under the leafless canopy of the forest. Rand sank into watchful silence, and for once even Mat had nothing to say.

ðət mɔɹnɪŋ ðə ɡeɪts ə fæl dæɹə hæɾ oʊpənd wɪð ðə dɔn. lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ, ɑɹmɝɾ ən hɛlməɾɪd naʊ laɪk ɪz soʊlʒɝz, ɹoʊd wɪð ðə blæk hɔk bænɝ ən ðə θɹi fɑksəz fɹəm ði ist ɡeɪt təwɔɹd ðə sʌn, stɪl oʊnli ə ɹɛd slɪvɝ əbʌv ðə tʃɹiz. laɪk ə stil sneɪk ʌnʒəleɪtɪŋ tə maʊntəd kɛɾəlɪdʒɹəmz, ðə kɑləm waʊn ɪts weɪ aʊɾ ə ðə taʊn fɔɹ əbɹɛst, eɪɡəlmɝ əɾ ɪts hɛd hɪɾən ɪn ðə fɔɹəs bɪfɔɹ ɪts teɪl lɛft fæl dæɹə kip. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ tʃɪɹz ɪn ðə stʃɹits tə spiɾ əm ɑn ðɛɹ weɪ, oʊnli ðɛɹ oʊn dʒɹʌmz ən ðɛɹ pɛnəns' kɹækɪŋ ɪn ðə wɪnd, bʌt ðɛɹ aɪz lʊk təwɔɹd ðə ɹaɪzɪŋ sʌn wɪð pɝpəs. istwɝd ðeɪ wəd dʒɔɪn ʌðɝ stil sɝpəns, fɹəm fæl mɝæn, bɪhaɪn kɪŋ isɑɹ hɪmsɛlf wɪð ɪz sʌnz əɾ ɪz saɪd, ən fɹəm ɑŋkɝ deɪl, ðət hɛl ði istɝn mɑɹtʃɪz ən ɡɑɹɾəd ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld; fɹəm mɔs ʃɪɹɛɹ ən fæl sən ən kæmɹən kɑn, ən ɔl ði ʌðɝ fɔɹtʃɹəsəz ɪn ʃaɪnɝ, ɡɹeɪɾ ən smɔl. dʒɔɪn ɪndə ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ sɝpənt, ðeɪ wəd tɝn nɔɹθ tə tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp.

That morning the gates of Fal Dara had opened with the dawn. Lord Agelmar, armored and helmeted now like his soldiers, rode with the Black Hawk banner and the Three Foxes from the East Gate toward the sun, still only a red sliver above the trees. Like a steel snake undulating to mounted kettledrums, the column wound its way out of the town four abreast, Agelmar at its head hidden in the forest before its tail left Fal Dara keep. There were no cheers in the streets to speed them on their way, only their own drums and their pennants' cracking in the wind, but their eyes looked toward the rising sun with purpose. Eastward they would join other steel serpents, from Fal Moran, behind King Easar himself with his sons at his side, and from Ankor Dail, that held the Eastern Marches and guarded the Spine of the World; from Mos Shirare and Fal Sion and Camron Caan, and all the other fortresses in Shienar, great and small. Joined into a greater serpent, they would turn north to Tarwin's Gap.

ənʌðɝ ɛksəɾəs hæd bɪɡʌn ət ðə seɪm taɪm, juzɪŋ ðə kɪŋz ɡeɪt ðət lɛɾ aʊɾ ɑn ðə weɪ tə fæl mɝæn. kɑɹts ən wæɡənz, pipəl maʊntəɾ ən pipəl əfʊt, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ðɛɹ laɪvstɑk, kæɹiɪŋ tʃɪlʒɹən ɑn ðɛɹ bæks, feɪsəz əz lɔŋ əz ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ʃædoʊz. ɹɪlʌktəns tə liv ðɛɹ hoʊmz, pɝhæps fɝɛvɝ, sloʊd ðɛɹ fit, jɛt fɪɹ ʌv wʌt wɑz kʌmɪŋ spɝd ðɛm, soʊ ðət ðeɪ wɛn ɪn bɝsts, fit dʒɹæɡɪŋ, ðən bɹeɪkɪŋ ɪndə ə ɹʌn fəɹ ə dʌzən peɪsɪz oʊnli tə fɔl bæk, wʌns mɔɹ, tə ʃʌflɪŋ θɹu ðə dʌst. ə fju pɔzd aʊtsaɪd ðə taʊn tə wɑtʃ ðə soʊlʒɝz' ɑɹmɝd laɪn waɪndɪŋ ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst. hoʊp blɑsəmd ɪn səm aɪz, ən pɹɛɹz wɝ mʌɾɝd, pɹɛɹz fəɹ ðə soʊlʒɝz, pɹɛɹz fəɹ ðɛmsɛlvz, bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ tɝn saʊθ əɡɛn, tʃɹʌdʒɪŋ.

Another exodus had begun at the same time, using the King's Gate that led out on the way to Fal Moran. Carts and wagons, people mounted and people afoot, driving their livestock, carrying children on their backs, faces as long as the morning shadows. Reluctance to leave their homes, perhaps forever, slowed their feet, yet fear of what was coming spurred them, so that they went in bursts, feet dragging, then breaking into a run for a dozen paces only to fall back, once more, to shuffling through the dust. A few paused outside the town to watch the soldiers' armored line winding into the forest. Hope blossomed in some eyes, and prayers were muttered, prayers for the soldiers, prayers for themselves, before they turned south again, trudging.

ðə smɔləs kɑləm wɛn aʊɾ ə ðə mɔlkiɝ ɡeɪt. lɛf bɪhaɪnd wɝ ə fju hu wəd ɹɪmeɪn, soʊlʒɝz ən ə spɹɪŋklɪŋ ʌv oʊldɝ mɛn, ðɛɹ waɪvz dɛɾ ən ðɛɹ ɡɹoʊn tʃɪlʒɹən meɪkɪŋ ðə sloʊ weɪ saʊθ. ə læs hændfʊl soʊ ðət wʌtɛvɝ hæpən ɪn tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp, fæl dæɹə wəd nɑt fɔl ʌndɪfɛndəd. ɪŋtʃɹz ɡɹeɪ aʊl lɛd ðə weɪ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz mɔɪɹeɪn u tʊk əm nɔɹθ. ðə moʊst ɪmpɔɹɾənt kɑləm ʌv ɔl, ən ðə moʊs dɛspɹɪt.

The smallest column went out of the Malkier Gate. Left behind were a few who would remain, soldiers and a sprinkling of older men, their wives dead and their grown children making the slow way south. A last handful so that Whatever happened in Tarwin's Gap, Fal Dara would not fall undefended. Ingtar's Gray Owl led the way, but it was Moiraine who took them north. The most important column of all, and the most desperate.

fəɹ ət list ən aʊɝ æftɝ ðeɪ pæs ðə bɔɹɾɝpoʊst ðəɹ wɑz noʊ tʃeɪnʒ ɪn læn əɹ fɔɹəst. ðə wɔɹɾɝ kɛpt əm əɾ ə hɑɹd peɪs, əz fæst ə wɔk əz ðə hɔɹsəz kəd meɪnteɪn, bʌt ɹænd kɛpt wʌndɝɪŋ wən ðeɪ wəd ɹitʃ ðə blaɪt. ðə hɪlz bɪkeɪm ə lɪɾəl haɪɝ, bʌt ðə tʃɹiz, ən ðə kɹipɝz, ən ði ʌndɝbɹʌʃ wɝ noʊ dɪfɹən ðən wʌɾ i hæd sin ɪn ʃaɪnɝ, ɡɹeɪ ən ɔl bʌt lifləs. hi bɪɡæn tə fil wɔɹmɝ, wɔɹm ɪnʌf tə slɪŋ ɪz kloʊk əkɹɔs ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl.

For at least an hour after they passed the borderpost there was no change in land or forest. The Warder kept them at a hard pace, as fast a walk as the horses could maintain, but Rand kept wondering when they would reach the Blight. The hills became a little higher, but the trees, and the creepers, and the underbrush were no different than what he had seen in Shienar, gray and all but leafless. He began to feel warmer, warm enough to sling his cloak across the pommel of his saddle.

"ðɪs ɪz ðə bɛst wɛðɝ wiv sin ɔl jɪɹ," ɛɡwin sɛd, ʃɹʌɡɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɝ oʊn kloʊk.

"This is the best weather we've seen all year," Egwene said, shrugging out of her own cloak.

nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ hɛd, fɹaʊnɪŋ əz ɪf lɪsnɪŋ tə ðə wɪnd. "ɪt filz ɹɔŋ."

Nynaeve shook her head, frowning as if listening to the wind. "It feels wrong."

ɹænd nɑɾəd. hi kəd fil ɪt, tu, ðoʊ hi kəd nɑt seɪ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ɪɡzækli hi wɑz filɪŋ. ðə ɹɔŋɡnəs wɛn bɪɑn ðə fɝst wɔɹmθ i kəd ɹɪmɛmbɝ aʊɾ ə dɔɹz ðɪs jɪɹ; ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən ðə sɪmpəl fæk ðəɾ ɪt ʃəd nɑt bi soʊ wɔɹm ðɪs fɑɹ nɔɹθ. ɪt mʌs bi ðə blaɪt, bʌt ðə lænd wɑz ðə seɪm.

Rand nodded. He could feel it, too, though he could not say what it was exactly he was feeling. The wrongness went beyond the first warmth he could remember out of doors this year; it was more than the simple fact that it should not be so warm this far north. It must be the Blight, but the land was the same.

ðə sʌn klaɪm haɪ, ə ɹɛd bɔl ðət kəd nɑt ɡɪv soʊ mʌtʃ wɔɹmθ dɪspaɪt ðə klaʊdləs skaɪ. ə lɪɾəl waɪl leɪɾɝ i ənbʌɾənd ɪz koʊt. swɛt tʃɹɪkəl daʊn ɪz feɪs.

The sun climbed high, a red ball that could not give so much warmth despite the cloudless sky. A little while later he unbuttoned his coat. Sweat trickled down his face.

hi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn. mæt tʊk ɪz koʊɾ ɔf, oʊpənli dɪspleɪɪŋ ðə ɡoʊld-ænd-ɹubi dæɡɝ, ən waɪpt ɪz feɪs wɪð ði ɛn ə hɪz skɑɹf. blɪŋkɪŋ, hi ɹiwaʊn ðə skɑɹf ɪndə ə nɛɹoʊ bæn loʊ oʊvɝ ɪz aɪz. nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin fæn ðɛmsɛlvz; ðeɪ ɹoʊd slʌmpt əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ wɪltɪŋ. lɔɪəl əndɪɾ ɪz haɪ-kɑlɝd tunɪk ɔl ðə weɪ daʊn, ən ɪz ʃɝɾ əz wɛl; ði oʊɡiɝ hæɾ ə nɛɹoʊ stʃɹɪp ə hɛɹ ʌp ðə mɪɾəl ə hɪz tʃɛst, əz θɪk əz fɝ. hi mʌɾɝd əpɑlədʒiz ɔl ɝaʊnd.

He was not the only one. Mat took his coat off, openly displaying the gold-and-ruby dagger, and wiped his face with the end of his scarf. Blinking, he rewound the scarf into a narrow band low over his eyes. Nynaeve and Egwene fanned themselves; they rode slumped as if they were wilting. Loial undid his high-collared tunic all the way down, and his shirt as well; the Ogier had a narrow strip of hair up the middle of his chest, as thick as fur. He muttered apologies all around.

"ju mʌs fɝɡɪv mi. stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ ɪz ɪn ðə maʊntənz, ən kul." hɪz bɹɔd nɑstʃɹəlz flɛɹd, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪn ɛɹ ðət wɑz bɪkʌmɪŋ wɔɹmɝ baɪ ðə mɪnət. "aɪ doʊn laɪk ðɪs hit, ən dæmp."

"You must forgive me. Stedding Shangtai is in the mountains, and cool." His broad nostrils flared, drawing in air that was becoming warmer by the minute. "I don't like this heat, and damp."

ɪt wɑz dæmp, ɹænd ɹilaɪzd. ɪt fɛlt laɪk ðə maɪɹ ɪn ðə dɛpθs ə sʌmɝ, bæk ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. ɪn ðət bɑi swɑmp ɛvɹi bɹɛθ keɪm əz ɪf θɹu ə wʊl blæŋkət soʊkt ɪn hɑt wɔɾɝ. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ sɑɡi ɡɹaʊn hɪɹ - oʊnli ə fju pɑnz ən stʃɹimz, tʃɹɪkəlz tə sʌmwʌn juz tə ðə wɔɾɝwʊd - bʌt ði ɛɹ wɑz laɪk ðəɾ ɪn ðə maɪɹ. oʊnli pɛɹɪn, stɪl ɪn ɪz koʊt, wɑz bɹiðɪŋ izəli. pɛɹɪn ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ.

It was damp, Rand realized. It felt like the Mire in the depths of summer, back in the Two Rivers. In that boggy swamp every breath came as if through a wool blanket soaked in hot water. There was no soggy ground here - only a few ponds and streams, trickles to someone used to the Waterwood - but the air was like that in the Mire. Only Perrin, still in his coat, was breathing easily. Perrin and the Warder.

ðəɹ wɝ ə fju livz naʊ, ɑn tʃɹiz ðət wɝ nɑɾ ɛvɝɡɹin. ɹænd ɹitʃt aʊt tə tʌtʃ ə bɹæntʃ, ən stɑpt wɪð ɪz hænd ʃɔɹɾ ə ðə livz. sɪkli jɛloʊ mɑɾəld ðə ɹɛɾ ə ðə nu ɡɹoʊθ, ən blæk flɛks laɪk dɪziz.

There were a few leaves now, on trees that were not evergreen. Rand reached out to touch a branch, and stopped with his hand short of the leaves. Sickly yellow mottled the red of the new growth, and black flecks like disease.

"aɪ toʊl jə nɑt tə tʌtʃ ɛniθɪŋ." ðə wɔɹɾɝz vɔɪs wɑz flæt. hi stɪl wɔɹ ɪz ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊk, əz ɪf hit meɪd noʊ mɔɹ ɪmpɹɛʃən ɑn ɪm ðən koʊld; ɪɾ ɔlmoʊs meɪɾ ɪz æŋɡjəlɝ feɪs sim tə floʊɾ ənsəpɔɹɾɪd əbʌv mændɑɹbz bæk. "flaʊɝz kən kɪl ɪn ðə blaɪt, ən livz meɪm. ðɛɹz ə lɪɾəl θɪŋ kɔld ə stɪk ðət laɪks tə haɪd wɛɹ ðə livz ɑɹ θɪkəst, lʊkɪŋ laɪk ɪts neɪm, weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ sʌmθɪŋ tə tʌtʃ ɪt. wən sʌmθɪŋ dʌz, ɪt baɪts. nɑt pɔɪzən. ðə dʒus bɪɡɪnz tə daɪdʒɛs ðə stɪks pɹeɪ fəɹ ɪt. ði oʊnli θɪŋ ðət kən seɪv jə ɪz tə kʌɾ ɔf ði ɑɹm əɹ lɛɡ ðət wɑz bɪɾən. bʌɾ ə stɪk woʊn baɪɾ ənlɛs jə tʌtʃ ɪt. ʌðɝ θɪŋz ɪn ðə blaɪt wɪl."

"I told you not to touch anything." The Warder's voice was flat. He still wore his shifting cloak, as if heat made no more impression on him than cold; it almost made his angular face seem to float unsupported above Mandarb's back. "Flowers can kill in the Blight, and leaves maim. There's a little thing called a Stick that likes to hide where the leaves are thickest, looking like its name, waiting for something to touch it. When something does, it bites. Not poison. The juice begins to digest the Stick's prey for it. The only thing that can save you is to cut off the arm or leg that was bitten. But a Stick won't bite unless you touch it. Other things in the Blight will."

ɹænd dʒɝkt ɪz hæn bæk, livz əntʌtʃt, ən waɪpt ɪɾ ɑn ɪz pæns lɛɡ.

Rand jerked his hand back, leaves untouched, and wiped it on his pants leg.

"ðɛn wɝ ɪn ðə blaɪt?" pɛɹɪn sɛd. stʃɹeɪnʒli, hi dɪd nɑt saʊn fɹaɪɾənd.

"Then we're in the Blight?" Perrin said. Strangely, he did not sound frightened.

"dʒʌs ðə fɹɪnʒ," læn sɛd ɡɹɪmli. hɪz stæljən kɛp muvɪŋ fɔɹwɝd, ən i spoʊk oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. "ðə ɹil blaɪt stɪl laɪz əhɛd. ðəɹ ɑɹ θɪŋz ɪn ðə blaɪt ðət hʌn baɪ saʊnd, ən səm meɪ hæv wɑndɝd ðɪs fɑɹ saʊθ. səmtaɪmz ðeɪ kɹɔs ðə maʊntənz ə dum. mʌtʃ wɝs ðən stɪks. kip kwaɪəɾ ən kip ʌp, ɪf jə wɑnə steɪ əlaɪv." hi kəntɪnjud tə sɛɾ ə hɑɹd peɪs, nɑt weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ ən ænsɝ.

"Just the fringe," Lan said grimly. His stallion kept moving forward, and he spoke over his shoulder. "The real Blight still lies ahead. There are things in the Blight that hunt by sound, and some may have wandered this far south. Sometimes they cross the Mountains of Dhoom. Much worse than Sticks. Keep quiet and keep up, if you want to stay alive." He continued to set a hard pace, not waiting for an answer.

maɪl baɪ maɪl ðə kɝʌpʃən ə ðə blaɪt bɪkeɪm mɔɹ əpɛɹənt. livz kʌvɝd ðə tʃɹiz ɪn ɛvɝ ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɹəfjuʒən, bʌt steɪn ən spɑɾəd wɪð jɛloʊ ən blæk, wɪð lɪvɪd ɹɛd stʃɹiks laɪk blʌd pɔɪzənɪŋ. ɛvɹi lif ən kɹipɝ sim bloʊɾɪd, ɹɛɾi tə bɝst əɾ ə tʌtʃ. flaʊɝz hʌŋ ɑn tʃɹiz ən widz ɪn ə pɛɹəɾi ʌv spɹɪŋ, sɪkli peɪl ən pʌlpi, wæksən θɪŋz ðəɾ əpɪɹd tə bi ɹɑɾɪŋ waɪl ɹænd wɑtʃt. wən i bɹið θɹu hɪz noʊz, ðə swit stɛntʃ ə dəkeɪ, hɛvi ən θɪk, sɪkən hɪm; wən i tʃɹaɪd bɹiðɪŋ θɹu hɪz maʊθ, hi ɔlmoʊst ɡæɡd. ði ɛɹ teɪstəd laɪk ə maʊθfʊl ə spɔɪl mit. ðə hɔɹsəz' hʊvz meɪɾ ə sɑf skwɪʃɪŋ əz ɹɑɾən-ɹaɪp θɪŋz bɹoʊk oʊpən ʌndɝ ðɛm.

Mile by mile the corruption of the Blight became more apparent. Leaves covered the trees in ever greater profusion, but stained and spotted with yellow and black, with livid red streaks like blood poisoning. Every leaf and creeper seemed bloated, ready to burst at a touch. Flowers hung on trees and weeds in a parody of spring, sickly pale and pulpy, waxen things that appeared to be rotting while Rand watched. When he breathed through his nose, the sweet stench of decay, heavy and thick, sickened him; when he tried breathing through his mouth, he almost gagged. The air tasted like a mouthful of spoiled meat. The horses' hooves made a soft squishing as rotten-ripe things broke open under them.

mæt lin aʊɾ ə hɪz sæɾəl ən spjuɾ əntɪl ɪz stʌmək wɑz ɛmpti. ɹænd sɔt ðə vɔɪd, bʌt kɑmnəs wɑz lɪɾəl hɛlp əɡɛns ðə bɝnɪŋ baɪl ðət kɛp kɹipɪŋ ʌp ɪz θɹoʊt. ɛmpti əɹ nɑt, mæt hivd əɡɛn ə maɪl leɪɾɝ, bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp nʌθɪŋ, ən jɛɾ əɡɛn æftɝ ðæt. ɛɡwin lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə bi sɪk, tu, swɑloʊɪŋ kɑnstənli, ən nɪneɪivz feɪs wɑz ə waɪt mæsk ə dɪtɝməneɪʃən, hɝ dʒɔ sɛɾ ən əɹ aɪz fɪkst ɑn mɔɪɹeɪnz bæk. ðə wɪzdəm wəd nɑɾ ədmɪt tə filɪŋ ɪl ənlɛs ði ɛɛs sədaɪ dɪd, fɝst, bʌt ɹænd dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ʃi wəɾ əv tə weɪt lɔŋ. mɔɪɹeɪnz aɪz wɝ taɪt, ən əɹ lɪps peɪl.

Mat leaned out of his saddle and spewed until his stomach was empty. Rand sought the void, but calmness was little help against the burning bile that kept creeping up his throat. Empty or not, Mat heaved again a mile later, bringing up nothing, and yet again after that. Egwene looked as if she wanted to be sick, too, swallowing constantly, and Nynaeve's face was a white mask of determination, her jaw set and her eyes fixed on Moiraine's back. The Wisdom would not admit to feeling ill unless the Aes Sedai did, first, but Rand did not think she would have to wait long. Moiraine's eyes were tight, and her lips pale.

dɪspaɪt ðə hiɾ ən dæmp, lɔɪəl ɹæpt ə skɑɹf ɝaʊn ɪz noʊz ən maʊθ. wən i mɛt ɹændz ɡeɪz, ði oʊɡiɝz aʊtʃɹeɪdʒ ən dɪsɡʌst wɝ pleɪn ɪn ɪz aɪz. "aɪ hæd hɝd - " hi bɪɡæn, hɪz vɔɪs mʌfəl baɪ ðə wʊl, ðən stɑp tə klɪɹ ɪz θɹoʊt wɪð ə ɡɹɪmɑs. "fɔ! ɪt teɪsts laɪk. . . . fɔ! aɪ hæd hɝɾ ən ɹɛɾ əbaʊt ðə blaɪt, bʌt nʌθɪŋ kəd dɪskɹaɪb. . . ." hɪz dʒɛstʃɝ sʌmhaʊ tʊk ɪn ðə smɛl əz wɛl əz ði aɪ-sɪkənɪŋ ɡɹoʊθ. "ðæɾ ivən ðə dɑɹk wʌn ʃəd də ðɪs tə tʃɹiz! fɔ!"

Despite the heat and damp, Loial wrapped a scarf around his nose and mouth. When he met Rand's gaze, the Ogier's outrage and disgust were plain in his eyes. "I had heard - " he began, his voice muffled by the wool, then stopped to clear his throat with a grimace. "Faugh! It tastes like. . . . Faugh! I had heard and read about the Blight, but nothing could describe. . . ." His gesture somehow took in the smell as well as the eye-sickening growth. "That even the Dark One should do this to trees! Faugh!"

ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz nɑɾ əfɛktəd, ʌv kɔɹs, ət lis nɑt ðət ɹænd kəd si, bʌt tə hɪz sɝpɹaɪz niðɝ wɑz pɛɹɪn. əɹ ɹæðɝ, nɑɾ ɪn ðə weɪ ðə ɹɛst ə ðɛm wɝ. ðə bɪɡ juθ ɡlɛɹɾ ət ði ɑbsin fɔɹəs θɹu wɪtʃ ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ əz i maɪɾ əv əɾ ən ɛnəmi, əɹ ðə bænɝ ʌv ən ɛnəmi. hi kɝɛs ði æks əɾ ɪz bɛlt əz ɪf ʌnəwɛɹ ʌv wʌɾ i wɑz duɪŋ, ən mʌɾɝd tə hɪmsɛlf, hæf ɡɹoʊlɪŋ ɪn ə weɪ ðət meɪd ðə hɛɹ ɑn ɹændz nɛk stɝ. ivən ɪn fʊl sʌnlaɪɾ ɪz aɪz ɡloʊd, ɡoʊldən ən fɪɹs.

The Warder was not affected, of course, at least not that Rand could see, but to his surprise neither was Perrin. Or rather, not in the way the rest of them were. The big youth glared at the obscene forest through which they rode as he might have at an enemy, or the banner of an enemy. He caressed the axe at his belt as if unaware of what he was doing, and muttered to himself, half growling in a way that made the hair on Rand's neck stir. Even in full sunlight his eyes glowed, golden and fierce.

ðə hit dɪd nɑɾ əbeɪɾ əz ðə blʌɾi sʌn fɛl təwɔɹd ðə hɝaɪzən. ɪn ðə dɪstəns tə ðə nɔɹθ, maʊntənz ɹoʊz, haɪɝ ðən ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst, blæk əɡɛns ðə skaɪ. səmtaɪmz ən aɪsi wɪn fɹəm ðə ʃɑɹp piks ɡʌstɪd fɑɹ ɪnʌf tə ɹitʃ ðɛm. ðə tɔɹəd hjumɪɾəti litʃt əweɪ moʊst ə ðə maʊntən tʃɪl, bʌt wʌt ɹɪmeɪnd wɑz wɪntɝ-koʊl kəmpɛɹd tə ðə swɛltɝ ɪt ɹipleɪst, ɪf dʒʌs fəɹ ə moʊmənt. ðə swɛɾ ɑn ɹændz feɪs sim tə flæʃ ɪndə bidz ʌv aɪs; əz ðə wɪn daɪd, ðə bidz mɛltəɾ əɡɛn, ɹʌnɪŋ æŋɡɹi laɪnz daʊn ɪz tʃiks, ən ðə θɪk hit ɹɪtɝn hɑɹɾɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ baɪ kəmpɛɹəsən. fəɹ ði ɪnstən ðə wɪn sɝaʊndəd ðɛm, ɪt swɛpt əweɪ ðə fɛɾɝ, jɛɾ i wʊɾə dʌn wɪθaʊt ðæt, tu, ɪf i kəd hæv. ðə koʊld wɑz ðə tʃɪl ə ðə ɡɹeɪv, ən ɪt kæɹid ðə dʌsti mʌst ʌv ən oʊl tum nuli oʊpənd.

The heat did not abate as the bloody sun fell toward the horizon. In the distance to the north, mountains rose, higher than the Mountains of Mist, black against the sky. Sometimes an icy wind from the sharp peaks gusted far enough to reach them. The torrid humidity leached away most of the mountain chill, but what remained was winter-cold compared to the swelter it replaced, if just for a moment. The sweat on Rand's face seemed to flash into beads of ice; as the wind died, the beads melted again, running angry lines down his cheeks, and the thick heat returned harder than before by comparison. For the instant the wind surrounded them, it swept away the fetor, yet he would have done without that, too, if he could have. The cold was the chill of the grave, and it carried the dusty must of an old tomb newly opened.

"wi kænɑt ɹitʃ ðə maʊntənz baɪ naɪtfɔl," læn sɛd, "æn ɪts deɪnʒɝəs tə muv ət naɪt, ivən fəɹ ə wɔɹɾɝ əloʊn."

"We cannot reach the mountains by nightfall," Lan said, "and it is dangerous to move at night, even for a Warder alone."

"ðɛɹ ɪz ə pleɪs nɑt fɑɹ ɔf," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ɪt wɪl bi ə ɡʊɾ oʊmən fəɹ əs tə kæmp ðɛɹ."

"There is a place not far off," Moiraine said. "It will be a good omen for us to camp there."

ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɡeɪv əɹ ə flæt lʊk, ðən nɑɾəd ɹɪlʌktənli. "jɛs. wi mʌs kæmp sʌmwɛɹ. ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl bi ðɛɹ."

The Warder gave her a flat look, then nodded reluctantly. "Yes. We must camp somewhere. It might as well be there."

"ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld wɑz bɪɑn ðə haɪ pæsəz wən aɪ faʊn ɪt," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "bɛɾɝ tə kɹɔs ðə maʊntənz ə dum ɪn fʊl deɪlaɪt, ət nun, wən ðə dɑɹk wʌnz paʊɝz ɪn ðɪs wɝld ɑɹ wikəst."

"The Eye of the World was beyond the high passes when I found it," Moiraine said. "Better to cross the Mountains of Dhoom in full daylight, at noon, when the Dark One's powers in this world are weakest."

"ju tɔk əz ɪf ði aɪ ɪzən ɔlweɪz ɪn ðə seɪm pleɪs." ɛɡwin spoʊk tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz lɔɪəl u ænsɝd.

"You talk as if the Eye isn't always in the same place." Egwene spoke to the Aes Sedai, but it was Loial who answered.

"noʊ tu əmʌŋ ði oʊɡiɝ əv faʊn ɪɾ ɪn ɪɡzækli ðə seɪm pleɪs. ðə ɡɹin mæn simz tə bi faʊnd wɛɹ hiz niɾəd. bʌɾ ɪts ɔlweɪz bɪn bɪɑn ðə haɪ pæsəz. ðeɪ ɑɹ tʃɹɛtʃɝəs, ðə haɪ pæsəz, ən hɔntəd baɪ kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn."

"No two among the Ogier have found it in exactly the same place. The Green Man seems to be found where he is needed. But it has always been beyond the high passes. They are treacherous, the high passes, and haunted by creatures of the Dark One."

"wi mʌst ɹitʃ ðə pæsəz bɪfɔɹ wi nid wɝi əbaʊt ðɛm," læn sɛd. "təmɑɹoʊ wɪl bi tʃɹuli ɪndə ðə blaɪt."

"We must reach the passes before we need worry about them," Lan said. "Tomorrow we will be truly into the Blight."

ɹænd lʊkt ət ðə fɔɹəst ɝaʊn hɪm, ɛvɹi lif ən flaʊɝ dɪzizd, ɛvɹi kɹipɝ dəkeɪɪŋ əz ɪt ɡɹu, ən i kəd nɑt ɹipɹɛs ə ʃʌɾɝ. ɪf ðɪs ɪzən tʃɹuli ðə blaɪt, wʌɾ ɪz?

Rand looked at the forest around him, every leaf and flower diseased, every creeper decaying as it grew, and he could not repress a shudder. If this isn't truly the Blight, what is?

læn tɝn əm wɛstwɝd, əɾ ən æŋɡəl tə ðə sɪŋkɪŋ sʌn. ðə wɔɹɾɝ meɪnteɪn ðə peɪs i hæd sɛt bɪfɔɹ, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ɹɪlʌktəns ɪn ðə sɛɾ ə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz.

Lan turned them westward, at an angle to the sinking sun. The Warder maintained the pace he had set before, but there was reluctance in the set of his shoulders.

ðə sʌn wɑz ə sʌlən ɹɛd bɔl dʒʌs tʌtʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹitɑps wən ðeɪ kɹɛstəɾ ə hɪl ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ dʒɹu ɹeɪn. bɪɑn əm tə ðə wɛs leɪ ə nɛtwɝk ə leɪks, ðə wɔɾɝz ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ dɑɹkli ɪn ðə slæntɪŋ sʌnlaɪt, laɪk bidz ə ɹændəm saɪz ɑn ə nɛkləs ə mɛni stʃɹɪŋz. ɪn ðə dɪstəns, sɝkəl baɪ ðə leɪks, stʊd dʒæɡd-tɑp hɪlz, θɪk ɪn ðə kɹipɪŋ ʃædoʊz ʌv ivnɪŋ. fəɹ wʌn bɹif ɪnstən ðə sʌnz ɹeɪz kɑt ðə ʃæɾɝd tɑps, ən ɹændz bɹɛθ stɪld. nɑt hɪlz. ðə bɹoʊkən ɹɛmnəns ə sɛvən taʊɝz. hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf ɛniwʌn ɛls hæd sin ɪt; ðə saɪt wɑz ɡɔn əz kwɪkli əz ɪt keɪm. ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz dɪsmaʊntɪŋ, hɪz feɪs əz lækɪŋ ɪn ɪmoʊʃən əz ə stoʊn.

The sun was a sullen red ball just touching the treetops when they crested a hill and the Warder drew rein. Beyond them to the west lay a network of lakes, the waters glittering darkly in the slanting sunlight, like beads of random size on a necklace of many strings. In the distance, circled by the lakes, stood jagged-topped hills, thick in the creeping shadows of evening. For one brief instant the sun's rays caught the shattered tops, and Rand's breath stilled. Not hills. The broken remnants of seven towers. He was not sure if anyone else had seen it; the sight was gone as quickly as it came. The Warder was dismounting, his face as lacking in emotion as a stone.

"kʊdnt wi kæmp daʊn baɪ ðə leɪks?" nɪneɪiv æskt, pæɾɪŋ əɹ feɪs wɪð əɹ kɝtʃəf. "ɪt mʌs bi kulɝ daʊn baɪ ðə wɔɾɝ."

"Couldn't we camp down by the lakes?" Nynaeve asked, patting her face with her kerchief. "It must be cooler down by the water."

"laɪt," mæt sɛd, "aɪd dʒʌs laɪk tə stɪk maɪ hɛɾ ɪn wʌn ə ðɛm. aɪ maɪt nɛvɝ teɪk ɪɾ aʊt."

"Light," Mat said, "I'd just like to stick my head in one of them. I might never take it out."

dʒʌs ðən sʌmθɪŋ ɹɔɪl ðə wɔɾɝz ə ðə nɪɹəs leɪk, ðə dɑɹk wɔɾɝ fɑsfɝɛsɪŋ əz ə hjudʒ bɑɾi ɹoʊl bɪniθ ðə sɝfəs. lɛŋθ ɑn mæn-θɪk lɛŋθ sɛn ɹɪpəlz spɹɛɾɪŋ, ɹoʊlɪŋ ɑn ən ɑn əntɪl ət læst ə teɪl ɹoʊz, weɪvɪŋ ə pɔɪn laɪk ə wɑsps stɪŋɝ fəɹ ən ɪnstən ɪn ðə twaɪlaɪt, ət lis faɪv spænz ɪndə ði ɛɹ. ɔl əlɔŋ ðət lɛŋθ fæt tɛntəkəlz ɹɪθ laɪk mɑnstʃɹəs wɝmz, əz mɛni əz ə sɛntɪpidz lɛɡz. ɪt slɪd sloʊli bɪniθ ðə sɝfəs ən wɑz ɡɔn, oʊnli ðə feɪɾɪŋ ɹɪpəlz tə seɪ ɪt hæɾ ɛvɝ bɪn.

Just then something roiled the waters of the nearest lake, the dark water phosphorescing as a huge body rolled beneath the surface. Length on man-thick length sent ripples spreading, rolling on and on until at last a tail rose, waving a point like a wasp's stinger for an instant in the twilight, at least five spans into the air. All along that length fat tentacles writhed like monstrous worms, as many as a centipede's legs. It slid slowly beneath the surface and was gone, only the fading ripples to say it had ever been.

ɹænd kloʊzd ɪz maʊθ ən ɪkstʃeɪnʒd ə lʊk wɪð pɛɹɪn. pɛɹɪnz jɛloʊ aɪz wɝ əz dɪsbɪlivɪŋ əz i nu hɪz oʊn mʌs bi. nʌθɪŋ ðət bɪɡ kəd lɪv ɪn ə leɪk ðət saɪz. ðoʊz kʊdn əv bɪn hænz ɑn ðoʊz tɛntəkəlz. ðeɪ kʊdn əv bɪn.

Rand closed his mouth and exchanged a look with Perrin. Perrin's yellow eyes were as disbelieving as he knew his own must be. Nothing that big could live in a lake that size. Those couldn't have been hands on those tentacles. They couldn't have been.

"ɑn sɛkən θɔt," mæt sɛd feɪnli, "aɪ laɪk ɪt ɹaɪt hɪɹ dʒʌs faɪn."

"On second thought," Mat said faintly, "I like it right here just fine."

"aɪ wɪl sɛt ɡɑɹɾɪŋ wɔɹdz ɝaʊn ðɪs hɪl," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dɪsmaʊntɪd fɹəm ɑldib. "ə tʃɹu bæɹiɝ wəd dʒɹɔ ði ətɛnʃən wi də nɑt wɑn laɪk flaɪz tə hʌni, bʌɾ ɪf ɛni kɹieɪʃən ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ðət sɝvz ðə ʃædoʊ kʌmz wɪðɪn ə maɪl ʌv ʌs, əl noʊ."

"I will set guarding wards around this hill," Moiraine said. She had already dismounted from Aldieb. "A true barrier would draw the attention we do not want like flies to honey, but if any creation of the Dark One or anything that serves the Shadow comes within a mile of us, I will know."

"aɪd bi hæpiɝ wɪð ðə bæɹiɝ," mæt sɛɾ əz ɪz buts tʌtʃt ðə ɡɹaʊnd, "dʒʌst əz lɔŋ əz ɪt kɛp ðæt, ðət . . . θɪŋ ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪd."

"I'd be happier with the barrier," Mat said as his boots touched the ground, "just as long as it kept that, that . . . thing on the other side."

"oʊ, də bi kwaɪət, mæt," ɛɡwin sɛd kɝtli, ət ðə seɪm taɪm əz nɪneɪiv spoʊk. "æn əv əm weɪɾɪŋ fəɹ əs wən wi liv ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ? jə ɑɹ ə ful, meɪtʃɹim kɔθən." mæt ɡlaʊɝɾ ət ðə tu wɪmən əz ðeɪ klaɪm daʊn, bʌɾ i kɛpt ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt.

"Oh, do be quiet, Mat," Egwene said curtly, at the same time as Nynaeve spoke. "And have them waiting for us when we leave in the morning? You are a fool, Matrim Cauthon." Mat glowered at the two women as they climbed down, but he kept his mouth shut.

əz i tʊk bɛləz ɹeɪnz, ɹænd ʃɛɹɾ ə ɡɹɪn wɪð pɛɹɪn. fəɹ ə moʊmən ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊs laɪk biɪŋ hoʊm, hævɪŋ mæt seɪɪŋ wʌɾ i ʃəd nɑɾ ət ðə wɝs pɑsəbəl taɪm. ðən ðə smaɪl feɪɾəd fɹəm pɛɹɪnz feɪs; ɪn ðə twaɪlaɪɾ ɪz aɪz dɪd ɡloʊ, əz ɪf ðeɪ hæɾ ə jɛloʊ laɪt bɪhaɪn ðɛm. ɹændz ɡɹɪn slɪpt əweɪ, tu. ɪɾ ɪzən laɪk hoʊm əɾ ɔl.

As he took Bela's reins, Rand shared a grin with Perrin. For a moment it was almost like being home, having Mat saying what he should not at the worst possible time. Then the smile faded from Perrin's face; in the twilight his eyes did glow, as if they had a yellow light behind them. Rand's grin slipped away, too. It isn't like home at all.

ɹænd ən mæt ən pɛɹɪn hɛlp læn ənsæɾəl ən hɑbəl ðə hɔɹsəz waɪl ði ʌðɝz bɪɡæn sɛɾɪŋ ʌp ðə kæmp. lɔɪəl mʌɾɝd tə hɪmsɛlf əz i sɛɾ ʌp ðə wɔɹɾɝz taɪni stoʊv, bʌɾ ɪz θɪk fɪŋɡɝz muv dɛfli. ɛɡwin wɑz hʌmɪŋ əz ʃi fɪl ðə ti kɛɾəl fɹəm ə bʌlʒɪŋ wɔɾɝbæɡ. ɹænd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wʌndɝd waɪ ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæɾ ɪnsɪstəɾ ɑn bɹɪŋɪŋ soʊ mɛni fʊl wɔɾɝskɪnz.

Rand and Mat and Perrin helped Lan unsaddle and hobble the horses while the others began setting up the camp. Loial muttered to himself as he set up the Warder's tiny stove, but his thick fingers moved deftly. Egwene was humming as she filled the tea kettle from a bulging waterbag. Rand no longer wondered why the Warder had insisted on bringing so many full waterskins.

sɛɾɪŋ ðə beɪz sæɾəl ɪn laɪn wɪð ði ʌðɝz, hi ənfæsən ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz ən blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl fɹəm ðə kæntəl, tɝnd, ən stɑpt wɪð ə tɪŋɡəl ə fɪɹ. ði oʊɡiɝ ən ðə wɪmən wɝ ɡɔn. soʊ wɑz ðə stoʊv ən ɔl ðə wɪkɝ pænɪɝz fɹəm ðə pæk hɔɹs. ðə hɪltɑp wɑz ɛmpti ɪksɛp fəɹ ivnɪŋ ʃædoʊz.

Setting the bay's saddle in line with the others, he unfastened his saddlebags and blanketroll from the cantle, turned, and stopped with a tingle of fear. The Ogier and the women were gone. So was the stove and all the wicker panniers from the pack horse. The hilltop was empty except for evening shadows.

wɪð ə nʌm hæn i fʌmbəl fəɹ ɪz sɔɹd, dɪmli hɪɹɪŋ mæt kɝs. pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɪz æks aʊt, hɪz ʃæɡi hɛd swɪvəlɪŋ tə faɪn ðə deɪnʒɝ.

With a numb hand he fumbled for his sword, dimly hearing Mat curse. Perrin had his axe out, his shaggy head swiveling to find the danger.

"ʃifɝɾɝz," læn mʌɾɝd. ʌnkənsɝnədli ðə wɔɹɾɝ stʃɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə hɪltɑp, ən əɾ ɪz θɝd stɛp, hi vænɪʃt.

"Sheepherders," Lan muttered. Unconcernedly the Warder strode across the hilltop, and at his third step, he vanished.

ɹænd ɪkstʃeɪnʒd waɪd-aɪd lʊks wɪð mæt ən pɛɹɪn, ən ðən ðeɪ wɝ ɔl dɑɹɾɪŋ fəɹ wɛɹ ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæd dɪsəpɪɹd. əbɹʌpli ɹænd skɪɾəd tə ə hɔlt, teɪkɪŋ ənʌðɝ stɛp wən mæt ɹæn ɪndə hɪz bæk. ɛɡwin lʊkt ʌp fɹəm sɛɾɪŋ ðə kɛɾəl ətɑp ðə taɪni stoʊv. nɪneɪiv wɑz kloʊzɪŋ ðə mæntəl ɑn ə sɛkən lɪt læntɝn. ðeɪ wɝ ɔl ðɛɹ, mɔɪɹeɪn sɪɾɪŋ kɹɔs-lɛɡəd, læn laʊnʒɪŋ ɑn ən ɛlboʊ, lɔɪəl teɪkɪŋ ə bʊk aʊɾ ə hɪz pæk.

Rand exchanged wide-eyed looks with Mat and Perrin, and then they were all darting for where the Warder had disappeared. Abruptly Rand skidded to a halt, taking another step when Mat ran into his back. Egwene looked up from setting the kettle atop the tiny stove. Nynaeve was closing the mantle on a second lit lantern. They were all there, Moiraine sitting cross-legged, Lan lounging on an elbow, Loial taking a book out of his pack.

kɔʃəsli ɹænd lʊk bɪhaɪn hɪm. ðə hɪlsaɪd wɑz ðəɹ əz ɪt hæd bɪn, ðə ʃæɾoʊd tʃɹiz, ðə leɪks bɪɑn sɪŋkɪŋ ɪndə dɑɹknəs. hi wɑz əfɹeɪd tə stɛp bæk, əfɹeɪd ðeɪ wəɾ ɔl dɪsəpɪɹ əɡɛn ən pɝhæps ðɪs taɪm i wəd nɑt bi eɪbəl tə faɪn ðɛm. ɛdʒɪŋ kɛɹfəli ɝaʊn hɪm, pɛɹɪn lɛɾ aʊɾ ə lɔŋ bɹɛθ.

Cautiously Rand looked behind him. The hillside was there as it had been, the shadowed trees, the lakes beyond sinking into darkness. He was afraid to step back, afraid they would all disappear again and perhaps this time he would not be able to find them. Edging carefully around him, Perrin let out a long breath.

mɔɪɹeɪn noʊɾəst ðə θɹi ʌv əm stændɪŋ ðɛɹ, ɡeɪpɪŋ. pɛɹɪn lʊkt əbæʃt, ən slɪpt ɪz æks bæk ɪndə ðə hɛvi bɛlt lup əz ɪf i θɔt noʊ wʌn maɪt noʊɾəs. ə smaɪl tʌtʃt əɹ lɪps. "ɪɾ ɪz ə sɪmpəl θɪŋ," ʃi sɛd, "ə bɛndɪŋ, soʊ ɛni aɪ lʊkɪŋ əɾ əs siz ɝaʊn ʌs, ɪnstɛd. wi kænɑɾ əv ði aɪz ðət wɪl bi aʊt ðəɹ siɪŋ əɹ laɪts tənaɪt, ən ðə blaɪɾ ɪz noʊ pleɪs tə bi ɪn ðə dɑɹk."

Moiraine noticed the three of them standing there, gaping. Perrin looked abashed, and slipped his axe back into the heavy belt loop as if he thought no one might notice. A smile touched her lips. "It is a simple thing," she said, "a bending, so any eye looking at us sees around us, instead. We cannot have the eyes that will be out there seeing our lights tonight, and the Blight is no place to be in the dark."

"mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛz aɪ maɪt bi eɪbəl tə də ɪt." ɛɡwinz aɪz wɝ bɹaɪt. "ʃi sɛz aɪ kən hændəl ɪnʌf ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɹaɪt naʊ."

"Moiraine Sedai says I might be able to do it." Egwene's eyes were bright. "She says I can handle enough of the One Power right now."

"nɑt wɪθaʊt tʃɹeɪnɪŋ, tʃaɪld," mɔɪɹeɪn kɑʃənd. "ðə sɪmpləs mæɾɝ kənsɝnɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ kən bi deɪnʒɝəs tə ði əntʃɹeɪnd, ən tə ðoʊz ɝaʊn ðɛm." pɛɹɪn snɔɹɾɪd, ən ɛɡwin lʊk soʊ ənkʌmftəɹbəl ðət ɹænd wʌndɝɾ ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi bɪn tʃɹaɪɪŋ əɹ əbɪləɾiz.

"Not without training, child," Moiraine cautioned. "The simplest matter concerning the One Power can be dangerous to the untrained, and to those around them." Perrin snorted, and Egwene looked so uncomfortable that Rand wondered if she had already been trying her abilities.

nɪneɪiv sɛt daʊn ðə læntɝn. təɡɛðɝ wɪð ðə taɪni fleɪm ə ðə stoʊv, ðə pɛɹ ə læntɝnz ɡeɪv ə dʒɛnɝəs laɪt. "wɛn jə ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ɛɡwin," ʃi sɛd kɛɹfəli, "pɝhæps əl ɡoʊ wɪð ju." ðə lʊk ʃi ɡeɪv mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz stʃɹeɪnʒli dɪfɛnsɪv. "ɪt wɪl də hɝ ɡʊd tə si ə fəmɪljɝ feɪs əmʌŋ stʃɹeɪnʒɝz. ʃɪl nid sʌmwʌn tə ædvaɪz əɹ bɪsaɪdz ɛɛs sədaɪ."

Nynaeve set down the lantern. Together with the tiny flame of the stove, the pair of lanterns gave a generous light. "When you go to Tar Valon, Egwene," she said carefully, "perhaps I'll go with you." The look she gave Moiraine was strangely defensive. "It will do her good to see a familiar face among strangers. She'll need someone to advise her besides Aes Sedai."

"pɝhæps ðət wəd bi fəɹ ðə bɛst, wɪzdəm," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd sɪmpli.

"Perhaps that would be for the best, Wisdom," Moiraine said simply.

ɛɡwin læft ən klæpt əɹ hænz. "oʊ, ðət wɪl bi wʌndɝfəl. ən ju, ɹænd. jəl kʌm, tu, woʊn ju?" hi pɔzd ɪn ði ækt ə sɪɾɪŋ əkɹɔs ðə stoʊv fɹəm hɝ, ðən sloʊli loʊɝd hɪmsɛlf. hi θɔɾ əɹ aɪz hæd nɛvɝ bɪn bɪɡɝ, əɹ bɹaɪɾɝ, əɹ mɔɹ laɪk pulz ðəɾ i kəd luz hɪmsɛlf ɪn. spɑts ə kʌlɝ əpɪɹɾ ɪn əɹ tʃiks, ən ʃi ɡeɪv ə smɔlɝ læf. "pɛɹɪn, mæt, jə tu wɪl kʌm, woʊn ju? wɪl ɔl bi təɡɛðɝ." mæt ɡeɪv ə ɡɹʌn ðət cʊɾə sɪɡnəfaɪɾ ɛniθɪŋ, ən pɛɹɪn oʊnli ʃɹʌɡd, bʌt ʃi tʊk ɪt fəɹ əsɛnt. "ju si, ɹænd. wɪl ɔl bi təɡɛðɝ."

Egwene laughed and clapped her hands. "Oh, that will be wonderful. And you, Rand. You'll come, too, won't you?" He paused in the act of sitting across the stove from her, then slowly lowered himself. He thought her eyes had never been bigger, or brighter, or more like pools that he could lose himself in. Spots of color appeared in her cheeks, and she gave a smaller laugh. "Perrin, Mat, you two will come, won't you? We'll all be together." Mat gave a grunt that could have signified anything, and Perrin only shrugged, but she took it for assent. "You see, Rand. We'll all be together."

laɪt, bʌɾ ə mæn kəd dʒɹaʊn ɪn ðoʊz aɪz ən bi hæpi duɪŋ ɪt. ɪmbɛɹəst, hi klɪɹɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. "du ðeɪv ʃip ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn? ðæts ɔl aɪ noʊ, hɝɾɪŋ ʃip ən ɡɹoʊɪŋ təbæk."

Light, but a man could drown in those eyes and be happy doing it. Embarrassed, he cleared his throat. "Do they have sheep in Tar Valon? That's all I know, herding sheep and growing tabac."

"aɪ bɪliv," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, "ðæɾ aɪ kən faɪn sʌmθɪŋ fəɹ jə tə də ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn. fəɹ ɔl ə ju. nɑt hɝɾɪŋ ʃip, pɝhæps, bʌt sʌmθɪŋ jəl faɪn ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ."

"I believe," Moiraine said, "that I can find something for you to do in Tar Valon. For all of you. Not herding sheep, perhaps, but something you will find interesting."

"ðɛɹ," ɛɡwin sɛɾ əz ɪf ɪt wɝ sɛɾəld. "aɪ noʊ. əl meɪk jə maɪ wɔɹɾɝ, wən ɪm ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. jə wəd laɪk biɪŋ ə wɔɹɾɝ, wʊdn ju? maɪ wɔɹɾɝ?" ʃi saʊndəd ʃʊɹ, bʌɾ i sɔ ðə kwɛstʃən ɪn əɹ aɪz. ʃi wɑntəɾ ən ænsɝ, niɾəd ɪt.

"There," Egwene said as if it were settled. "I know. I will make you my Warder, when I'm an Aes Sedai. You would like being a Warder, wouldn't you? My Warder?" She sounded sure, but he saw the question in her eyes. She wanted an answer, needed it.

"aɪd laɪk biɪŋ jəɹ wɔɹɾɝ," hi sɛd. ʃiz nɑt fəɹ ju, nɔɹ jə fəɹ hɝ. waɪ dɪd mɪn əv tə tɛl mi ðæt?

"I'd like being your Warder," he said. She's not for you, nor you for her. Why did Min have to tell me that?

dɑɹknəs keɪm daʊn hɛvəli, ən ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz taɪɝd. lɔɪəl wɑz ðə fɝs tə ɹoʊl oʊvɝ ən ɹɛɾi hɪmsɛlf fəɹ slip, bʌɾ ʌðɝz fɑloʊd sun æftɝ. noʊ wʌn juz ðɛɹ blæŋkəts, ɪksɛp fəɹ ə pɪloʊ. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd pʊt sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ði ɔɪl ə ðə læmps ðət dɪspɛl ðə stɛntʃ ə ðə blaɪt fɹəm ðə hɪltɑp, bʌt nʌθɪŋ dɪmɪnɪʃt ðə hit. ðə mun ɡeɪv ə weɪvɝɪŋ, wɔɾɝi laɪt, bʌt ðə sʌn maɪɾ əv bɪn əɾ ɪts zinəθ fəɹ ɔl ðə kul ðə naɪt hæd.

Darkness came down heavily, and everyone was tired. Loial was the first to roll over and ready himself for sleep, but others followed soon after. No one used their blankets, except for a pillow. Moiraine had put something in the oil of the lamps that dispelled the stench of the Blight from the hilltop, but nothing diminished the heat. The moon gave a wavering, watery light, but the sun might have been at its zenith for all the cool the night had.

ɹænd faʊn slip ɪmpɑsəbəl, ivən wɪð ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stʃɹɛtʃt aʊt nɑɾ ə spæn əweɪ tə ʃild ɪz dʒɹimz. ɪt wɑz ðə θɪk ɛɹ ðət kɛpt ɪm əweɪk. lɔɪəlz sɑf snɔɹz wɝ ə ɹʌmbəl ðət meɪd pɛɹɪnz sim nɑnəɡzɪstənt, bʌt ðeɪ dɪd nɑt stɑp wɪɹinəs fɹəm kleɪmɪŋ ði ʌðɝz. ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz stɪl əweɪk, siɾəd nɑt fɑɹ fɹəm ɪm wɪð ɪz sɔɹɾ əkɹɔs ɪz niz, wɑtʃɪŋ ðə naɪt. tə ɹændz sɝpɹaɪz, soʊ wɑz nɪneɪiv.

Rand found sleep impossible, even with the Aes Sedai stretched out not a span away to shield his dreams. It was the thick air that kept him awake. Loial's soft snores were a rumble that made Perrin's seem nonexistent, but they did not stop weariness from claiming the others. The Warder was still awake, seated not far from him with his sword across his knees, watching the night. To Rand's surprise, so was Nynaeve.

ðə wɪzdəm lʊkt ət læn saɪlənli fəɹ ə lɔŋ taɪm, ðən pɔɹɾ ə kʌp ə ti ən bɹɔɾ ɪt tə hɪm. wən i ɹitʃt aʊt wɪð ə mɝmɝ ə θæŋks, ʃi dɪd nɑt lɛt ɡoʊ ɹaɪɾ əweɪ. "aɪ ʃʊɾə noʊn jə wəd bi ə kɪŋ," ʃi sɛd kwaɪətli. hɝ aɪz wɝ stɛɾi ɑn ðə wɔɹɾɝz feɪs, bʌɾ əɹ vɔɪs tʃɹɛmbəl slaɪtli.

The Wisdom looked at Lan silently for a long time, then poured a cup of tea and brought it to him. When he reached out with a murmur of thanks, she did not let go right away. "I should have known you would be a king," she said quietly. Her eyes were steady on the Warder's face, but her voice trembled slightly.

læn lʊk bæk əɾ əɹ dʒʌst əz ɪntɛnli. ɪt sim tə ɹænd ðət ðə wɔɹɾɝz feɪs æktʃəli  sɔfənd. "aɪ æm nɑɾ ə kɪŋ, nɪneɪiv. dʒʌst ə mæn. ə mæn wɪθaʊɾ əz mʌtʃ tə hɪz neɪm əz ivən ðə minəs fɑɹmɝz kɹɔft."

Lan looked back at her just as intently. It seemed to Rand that the Warder's face actually softened. "I am not a king, Nynaeve. Just a man. A man without as much to his name as even the meanest farmer's croft."

nɪneɪivz vɔɪs stɛɾid. "sʌm wɪmən doʊn æsk fəɹ lænd, əɹ ɡoʊld. dʒʌs ðə mæn."

Nynaeve's voice steadied. "Some women don't ask for land, or gold. Just the man."

"æn ðə mæn u wəɾ æsk əɹ tə æksɛp soʊ lɪɾəl wəd nɑt bi wɝði ʌv hɝ. jə ɑɹ ə ɹɪmɑɹkəbəl wʊmən, əz bjuɾəfəl əz ðə sʌnɹaɪz, əz fɪɹs əz ə wɔɹiɝ. jə ɑɹ ə laɪoʊnəs, wɪzdəm."

"And the man who would ask her to accept so little would not be worthy of her. You are a remarkable woman, as beautiful as the sunrise, as fierce as a warrior. You are a lioness, Wisdom."

"eɪ wɪzdəm sɛldəm wɛdz." ʃi pɔz tə teɪk ə dip bɹɛθ, əz ɪf stilɪŋ hɝsɛlf. "bʌɾ ɪf aɪ ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn, ɪt meɪ bi ðəɾ əl bi sʌmθɪŋ ʌðɝ ðən ə wɪzdəm."

"A Wisdom seldom weds." She paused to take a deep breath, as if steeling herself. "But if I go to Tar Valon, it may be that I will be something other than a Wisdom."

"ɛɛs sədaɪ mɛɹi əz sɛldəm əz wɪsdəmz. fju mɛn kən lɪv wɪð soʊ mʌtʃ paʊɝ ɪn ə waɪf, dɪmɪŋ əm baɪ hɝ ɹeɪdʒjəns wɛðɝ ʃi wɪʃɪz tə əɹ nɑt."
