"Aes Sedai marry as seldom as Wisdoms. Few men can live with so much power in a wife, dimming them by her radiance whether she wishes to or not."

"sʌm mɛn ɑɹ stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf. aɪ noʊ wʌn sʌtʃ." ɪf ðəɹ cʊɾə bɪn ɛni daʊt, hɝ lʊk lɛf nʌn əz tə hum ʃi mɛnt.

"Some men are strong enough. I know one such." If there could have been any doubt, her look left none as to whom she meant.

"ɔl aɪ hæv ɪz ə sɔɹd, ən ə wɔɹ wʌn kænɑt wɪn, bʌt kən nɛvɝ stɑp faɪɾɪŋ."

"All I have is a sword, and a war I cannot win, but can never stop fighting."

"aɪv toʊl jə aɪ kɛɹ nʌθɪŋ fəɹ ðæt. laɪt, juv meɪd mi seɪ mɔɹ ðən ɪz pɹɑpɝ ɔlɹɛɾi. wɪl jə ʃeɪm mi tə ðə pɔɪn ʌv æskɪŋ ju?"

"I've told you I care nothing for that. Light, you've made me say more than is proper already. Will you shame me to the point of asking you?"

"aɪ wɪl nɛvɝ ʃeɪm ju." ðə dʒɛntəl toʊn, laɪk ə kɝɛs, saʊndəɾ ɑd tə ɹændz ɪɹz ɪn ðə wɔɹɾɝz vɔɪs, bʌɾ ɪt meɪd nɪneɪivz aɪz bɹaɪɾən. "aɪ wɪl heɪt ðə mæn jə tʃuz kəz hiz nɑt mi, ən lʌv ɪm ɪf i meɪks jə smaɪl. noʊ wʊmən dɪzɝvz ðə ʃʊɹ nɑlədʒ ʌv wɪɾoʊz blæk əz əɹ bɹɪɾɪpɹaɪs, jə list ʌv ɔl." hi sɛt ði əntʌtʃt kʌp ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ən ɹoʊz. "aɪ mʌs tʃɛk ðə hɔɹsəz."

"I will never shame you." The gentle tone, like a caress, sounded odd to Rand's ears in the Warder's voice, but it made Nynaeve's eyes brighten. "I will hate the man you choose because he is not me, and love him if he makes you smile. No woman deserves the sure knowledge of widow's black as her brideprice, you least of all." He set the untouched cup on the ground and rose. "I must check the horses."

nɪneɪiv ɹɪmeɪn ðɛɹ, nilɪŋ, æftɝ i hæd ɡɔn.

Nynaeve remained there, kneeling, after he had gone.

slip əɹ noʊ, ɹænd kloʊzd ɪz aɪz. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ðə wɪzdəm wəd laɪk ɪɾ ɪf i wɑtʃt əɹ kɹaɪ.

Sleep or no, Rand closed his eyes. He did not think the Wisdom would like it if he watched her cry.


tʃæptɝ fɔɹɾinaɪn


CHAPTER 49

ðə dɑɹk wʌn stɝz


The Dark One Stirs

dɔn woʊk ɹænd wɪð ə stɑɹt, ðə sʌlən sʌn pɹɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪlɪdz əz ɪt pikt ɹɪlʌktənli oʊvɝ ðə tʃɹitɑps ə ðə blaɪt. ivən soʊ ɝli, hit kʌvɝd ðə spɔɪld lænz ɪn ə hɛvi blæŋkət. hi leɪ ɑn ɪz bæk wɪð ɪz hɛd pɪloʊɾ ɑn ɪz blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə skaɪ. ɪt wɑz stɪl blu, ðə skaɪ. ivən hɪɹ, ðæt, ət list, wɑz əntʌtʃt.

Dawn woke Rand with a start, the sullen sun pricking his eyelids as it peeked reluctantly over the treetops of the Blight. Even so early, heat covered the spoiled lands in a heavy blanket. He lay on his back with his head pillowed on his blanketroll, staring at the sky. It was still blue, the sky. Even here, that, at least, was untouched.

hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i hæd slɛpt. fəɹ ə mɪnət ðə dɪm mɛmɹi ʌv ə kɑnvɝseɪʃən oʊvɝhɝd sim laɪk pɑɹɾ ə səm dʒɹim. ðən i sɔ nɪneɪivz ɹɛd-ɹɪmd aɪz; ʃi hæd nɑt slɛpt, ɑbviəsli. lænz feɪs wɑz hɑɹɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ, əz ɪf i hæd ɹɪzumd ə mæsk ən dɪd nɑɾ ɪntɛn tə lɛɾ ɪt slɪp əɡɛn.

He was surprised to realize that he had slept. For a minute the dim memory of a conversation overheard seemed like part of some dream. Then he saw Nynaeve's red-rimmed eyes; she had not slept, obviously. Lan's face was harder than ever, as if he had resumed a mask and did not intend to let it slip again.

ɛɡwin wɛn oʊvɝ ən kɹaʊtʃt bɪsaɪd ðə wɪzdəm, hɝ feɪs kənsɝnd. hi kəd nɑt meɪk aʊt wʌt ðeɪ sɛd. ɛɡwin spoʊk, ən nɪneɪiv ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. ɛɡwin sɛd sʌmθɪŋ ɛls, ən ðə wɪzdəm weɪvd əɹ əweɪ dɪsmɪsɪvli. ɪnstɛɾ ʌv ɡoʊɪŋ, ɛɡwin bɛn əɹ hɛd kloʊsɝ, ən fəɹ ə fju mɪnəts ðə tu wɪmən tɔkt ivən mɔɹ sɔfli, wɪð nɪneɪiv stɪl ʃeɪkɪŋ əɹ hɛd. ðə wɪzdəm ɛndəɾ ɪt wɪð ə læf, hʌɡɪŋ ɛɡwin ænd, baɪ hɝ ɪkspɹɛʃən, meɪkɪŋ suðɪŋ tɔk. wən ɛɡwin stʊd, ðoʊ, ʃi ɡlɛɹɾ ət ðə wɔɹɾɝ. læn dɪd nɑt sim tə noʊɾəs; hi dɪd nɑt lʊk ɪn nɪneɪivz dɝɛkʃən əɾ ɔl.

Egwene went over and crouched beside the Wisdom, her face concerned. He could not make out what they said. Egwene spoke, and Nynaeve shook her head. Egwene said something else, and the Wisdom waved her away dismissively. Instead of going, Egwene bent her head closer, and for a few minutes the two women talked even more softly, with Nynaeve still shaking her head. The Wisdom ended it with a laugh, hugging Egwene and, by her expression, making soothing talk. When Egwene stood, though, she glared at the Warder. Lan did not seem to notice; he did not look in Nynaeve's direction at all.

ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, ɹænd ɡæðɝɾ ɪz θɪŋz, ən ɡeɪv ɪz hænz ən feɪs ən tiθ ə heɪsti wɑʃ wɪð ðə lɪɾəl wɔɾɝ læn əlaʊd fəɹ sətʃ θɪŋz. hi wʌndɝɾ ɪf wɪmən hæɾ ə weɪ ʌv ɹiɾɪŋ mɛnz maɪnz. ɪt wɑz ən ənsɛɾəlɪŋ θɔt. ɔl wɪmən ɑɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ. tɛlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf i wɑz lɛɾɪŋ ðə blaɪt ɡɛt tə hɪm, hi ɹɪnst aʊɾ ɪz maʊθ ən hɝid tə ɡɛt ðə beɪ sæɾəld.

Shaking his head, Rand gathered his things, and gave his hands and face and teeth a hasty wash with the little water Lan allowed for such things. He wondered if women had a way of reading men's minds. It was an unsettling thought. All women are Aes Sedai. Telling himself he was letting the Blight get to him, he rinsed out his mouth and hurried to get the bay saddled.

ɪt wɑz mɔɹ ðən ə lɪɾəl dɪskənsɝɾɪŋ, hævɪŋ ðə kæmpsaɪt dɪsəpɪɹ bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ðə hɔɹsəz, bʌt baɪ ðə taɪm ɪz sæɾəl ɡɝθ wɑz taɪɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ɑn ðə hɪl wɪŋk bæk ɪndə vju. ɛvɹiwʌn wɑz hɝiɪŋ.

It was more than a little disconcerting, having the campsite disappear before he reached the horses, but by the time his saddle girth was tight everything on the hill winked back into view. Everyone was hurrying.

ðə sɛvən taʊɝz stʊd pleɪn ɪn ðə mɔɹnɪŋ laɪt, dɪstən bɹoʊkən stʌmps, laɪk hjudʒ, ɹʌf hɪlz ðət mɪɹli hɪntəɾ ət ɡɹænduɹ ɡɔn. ðə hʌnʒɹəd leɪks wɝ ə smuð, ənɹʌfəl blu. nʌθɪŋ bɹoʊk ðə sɝfəs ðɪs mɔɹnɪŋ. wən i lʊkt ət ðə leɪks ən ðə ɹuən taʊɝz, hi kəɾ ɔlmoʊst ɪɡnɔɹ ðə sɪkli θɪŋz ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɝaʊn ðə hɪl. læn dɪd nɑt sim tə bi əvɔɪɾɪŋ lʊkɪŋ ət ðə taʊɝz, ɛni mɔɹ ðən i sim tə bi əvɔɪɾɪŋ nɪneɪiv, bʌt sʌmhaʊ hi nɛvɝ dɪɾ əz i kɑnsəntʃɹeɪɾəd ɑn ɡɛɾɪŋ əm ɹɛɾi tə ɡoʊ.

The seven towers stood plain in the morning light, distant broken stumps, like huge, rough hills that merely hinted at grandeur gone. The hundred lakes were a smooth, unruffled blue. Nothing broke the surface this morning. When he looked at the lakes and the ruined towers, he could almost ignore the sickly things growing around the hill. Lan did not seem to be avoiding looking at the towers, any more than he seemed to be avoiding Nynaeve, but somehow he never did as he concentrated on getting them ready to go.

æftɝ ðə wɪkɝ pænɪɝz wɝ fæsən ɑn ðə pæk hɔɹs, æftɝ ɛvɹi skɹæp ən smʌdʒ ən tʃɹæk wɝ ɡɔn ən ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls wɑz maʊntəd, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ stʊɾ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə hɪltɑp wɪð əɹ aɪz kloʊzd, nɑɾ ivən simɪŋ tə bɹið. nʌθɪŋ hæpən ðət ɹænd kəd si, ɪksɛp ðət nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin ʃɪvɝd dɪspaɪt ðə hiɾ ən ɹʌb ðɛɹ ɑɹmz bɹɪskli. ɛɡwinz hænz sʌɾənli fɹoʊz ɑn əɹ ɑɹmz, ən ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə wɪzdəm. bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd spik, nɪneɪiv ɔlsoʊ sist əɹ ɹʌbɪŋ ən ɡeɪv əɹ ə ʃɑɹp lʊk. ðə tu wɪmən lʊkt ət wʌn ənʌðɝ, ðən ɛɡwin nɑɾəd ən ɡɹɪnd, ən æftɝ ə moʊmənt nɪneɪiv dɪd, tu, ðoʊ hɝ smaɪl wɑz oʊnli hæfhɑɹɾɪd.

After the wicker panniers were fastened on the pack horse, after every scrap and smudge and track were gone and everyone else was mounted, the Aes Sedai stood in the middle of the hilltop with her eyes closed, not even seeming to breathe. Nothing happened that Rand could see, except that Nynaeve and Egwene shivered despite the heat and rubbed their arms briskly. Egwene's hands suddenly froze on her arms, and she opened her mouth, staring at the Wisdom. Before she could speak, Nynaeve also ceased her rubbing and gave her a sharp look. The two women looked at one another, then Egwene nodded and grinned, and after a moment Nynaeve did, too, though her smile was only halfhearted.

ɹænd skɹʌbd ɪz fɪŋɡɝz θɹu hɪz hɛɹ, ɔlɹɛɾi mɔɹ dæmp wɪð swɛt ðən wɪð ðə wɔɾɝ i hæd splæʃt ɪn ɪz feɪs. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə saɪlən ɪkstʃeɪnʒ ðəɾ i ʃəɾ ʌndɝstænd, bʌt ðət fɛðɝ-laɪt bɹʌʃ əkɹɔs ɪz maɪn vænɪʃt bɪfɔɹ i kəd ɡɹæsp ɪt.

Rand scrubbed his fingers through his hair, already more damp with sweat than with the water he had splashed in his face. He was sure there was something in the silent exchange that he should understand, but that feather-light brush across his mind vanished before he could grasp it.

"wʌɾ ɑɹ wi weɪɾɪŋ fɔɹ?" mæt dɪmændəd, ðə loʊ bæn ə hɪz skɑɹf əkɹɔs ɪz fɔɹhɛd. hi hæɾ ɪz baʊ əkɹɔs ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl wɪð ən æɹoʊ nɑkt, ən ɪz kwɪvɝ pʊld ɝaʊn ɑn ɪz bɛl fəɹ ən izi ɹitʃ.

"What are we waiting for?" Mat demanded, the low band of his scarf across his forehead. He had his bow across the pommel of his saddle with an arrow nocked, and his quiver pulled around on his belt for an easy reach.

mɔɪɹeɪn oʊpən əɹ aɪz ən stɑɹɾəd daʊn ðə hɪl. "fɔɹ mi tə ɹimuv ðə læs vɛstɪdʒ ʌv wʌɾ aɪ dɪd hɪɹ læs naɪt. ðə ɹɛzəduz wʊɾə dɪsəpeɪɾɪd ɑn ðɛɹ oʊn ɪn ə deɪ, bʌɾ əl nɑt teɪk ɛni ɹɪsk aɪ kən əvɔɪd naʊ. wəɹ tu kloʊz, ən ðə ʃædoʊ ɪz tu stʃɹɔŋ hɪɹ. læn?"

Moiraine opened her eyes and started down the hill. "For me to remove the last vestige of what I did here last night. The residues would have dissipated on their own in a day, but I will not take any risk I can avoid now. We are too close, and the Shadow is too strong here. Lan?"

ðə wɔɹɾɝ oʊnli weɪɾəd fəɹ əɹ tə sɛɾəl ɪn ɑldibz sæɾəl bɪfɔɹ i lɛɾ əm nɔɹθ, təwɔɹd ðə maʊntənz ə dum, lumɪŋ ɪn ðə nɪɹ dɪstəns. ivən ʌndɝ ðə sʌnɹaɪz ðə piks ɹoʊz blæk ən laɪfləs, laɪk dʒæɡd tiθ. ɪn ə wɔl ðeɪ stʃɹɛtʃt, ist ən wɛst əz fɑɹ əz ði aɪ kəd si.

The Warder only waited for her to settle in Aldieb's saddle before he led them north, toward the Mountains of Dhoom, looming in the near distance. Even under the sunrise the peaks rose black and lifeless, like jagged teeth. In a wall they stretched, east and west as far as the eye could see.

"wɪl wi ɹitʃ ði aɪ tədeɪ, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ?" ɛɡwin æskt.

"Will we reach the Eye today, Moiraine Sedai?" Egwene asked.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪv lɔɪəl ə saɪɾɛlɔŋ lʊk. "aɪ hoʊp ðət wi wɪl. wən aɪ faʊn ɪt bɪfɔɹ, ɪt wɑz dʒʌs ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə maʊntənz, ət ðə fʊɾ ə ðə haɪ pæsəz."

The Aes Sedai gave Loial a sidelong look. "I hope that we will. When I found it before, it was just the other side of the mountains, at the foot of the high passes."

"hi sɛz ɪt muvz," mæt sɛd, nɑɾɪŋ ət lɔɪəl. "wʌɾ ɪf ɪɾ ɪzənt wɛɹ jə ɪkspɛkt?"

"He says it moves," Mat said, nodding at Loial. "What if it isn't where you expect?"

"ðɛn wɪl kəntɪnju tə hʌn əntɪl wi də faɪn ɪt. ðə ɡɹin mæn sɛnsɪz nid, ən ðəɹ kən bi noʊ nid ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən aʊɝz. əɹ niɾ ɪz ðə hoʊp ə ðə wɝld."

"Then we will continue to hunt until we do find it. The Green Man senses need, and there can be no need greater than ours. Our need is the hope of the world."

əz ðə maʊntənz dʒɹu kloʊsɝ, soʊ dɪd ðə tʃɹu blaɪt. wɛɹ ə lif hæd bɪn spɑɾəd blæk ən mɑɾəld jɛloʊ bɪfɔɹ, naʊ foʊlɪdʒ fɛl wɛtli waɪl i wɑtʃt, bɹeɪkɪŋ əpɑɹt fɹəm ðə weɪɾ ʌv ɪts oʊn kɝʌpʃən. ðə tʃɹiz ðɛmsɛlvz wɝ tɔɹtʃɝd, kɹɪpəl θɪŋz, twɪstəd bɹæntʃəz klɔɪŋ ət ðə skaɪ əz ɪf bɛɡɪŋ mɝsi fɹəm səm paʊɝ ðət ɹəfjuz tə hɪɹ. uz slɪd laɪk pʌs fɹəm bɑɹk kɹækt ən splɪt. əz ɪf nʌθɪŋ tʃɹuli sɑləd wɑz lɛf tə ðɛm, ðə tʃɹiz sim tə tʃɹɛmbəl fɹəm ðə pæsədʒ ə ðə hɔɹsəz oʊvɝ ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

As the mountains drew closer, so did the true Blight. Where a leaf had been spotted black and mottled yellow before, now foliage fell wetly while he watched, breaking apart from the weight of its own corruption. The trees themselves were tortured, crippled things, twisted branches clawing at the sky as if begging mercy from some power that refused to hear. Ooze slid like pus from bark cracked and split. As if nothing truly solid was left to them, the trees seemed to tremble from the passage of the horses over the ground.

"lʊk əz ɪf ðeɪ wɑnə ɡɹæb ʌs," mæt sɛd nɝvəsli. nɪneɪiv ɡeɪv ɪm ən ɪɡzæspɝeɪɾɪd, skɔɹnfəl lʊk, ən i æɾəd fɪɹsli, "wɛl, ðeɪ də lʊk ɪt."

"Look as if they want to grab us," Mat said nervously. Nynaeve gave him an exasperated, scornful look, and he added fiercely, "Well, they do look it."

"æn səm ə ðɛm də wɑn ɪt," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd. hɝ aɪz oʊvɝ əɹ ʃoʊldɝ wɝ hɑɹɾɝ ðən lænz fəɹ ən ɪnstənt. "bʌt ðeɪ wɑnt noʊ pɑɹɾ ʌv wʌɾ aɪ æm, ən maɪ pɹɛzəns pɹətɛks ju."

"And some of them do want it," the Aes Sedai said. Her eyes over her shoulder were harder than Lan's for an instant. "But they want no part of what I am, and my presence protects you."

mæt læft ənizəli, əz ɪf i θɔɾ ɪɾ ə dʒoʊk ɑn əɹ pɑɹt.

Mat laughed uneasily, as if he thought it a joke on her part.

ɹænd wɑz nɑt soʊ ʃʊɹ. ðɪs wɑz ðə blaɪt, æftɝ ɔl. bʌt tʃɹiz doʊn muv. waɪ wəɾ ə tʃɹi ɡɹæb ə mæn, ivən ɪf ɪt kʊd? wɝ ɪmædʒənɪŋ θɪŋz, ən ʃiz dʒʌs tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kip əs əlɝt.

Rand was not so sure. This was the Blight, after all. But trees don't move. Why would a tree grab a man, even if it could? We're imagining things, and she's just trying to keep us alert.

əbɹʌpli hi stɛɹɾ ɔf tə hɪz lɛft, ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst. ðət tʃɹi, nɑt twɛnti peɪsɪz əweɪ, hæd tʃɹɛmbəld, ən ɪt wɑz nʌn ə hɪz ɪmædʒəneɪʃən. hi kəd nɑt seɪ wʌt kaɪn ɪt wɑz, əɹ hæd bɪn, soʊ nɑɹld ən tɔɹmɛntɪd wɑz ɪts ʃeɪp. əz i wɑtʃt, ðə tʃɹi sʌɾənli wɪp bæk ən fɔɹθ əɡɛn, ðən bɛn daʊn, fleɪlɪŋ ət ðə ɡɹaʊnd. sʌmθɪŋ skɹimd, ʃɹɪl ən pɪɹsɪŋ. ðə tʃɹi spɹæŋ bæk stʃɹeɪt; ɪts lɪmz ɛntwaɪn ɝaʊn ə dɑɹk mæs ðət ɹɪθd ən spæɾ ən skɹimd.

Abruptly he stared off to his left, into the forest. That tree, not twenty paces away, had trembled, and it was none of his imagination. He could not say what kind it was, or had been, so gnarled and tormented was its shape. As he watched, the tree suddenly whipped back and forth again, then bent down, flailing at the ground. Something screamed, shrill and piercing. The tree sprang back straight; its limbs entwined around a dark mass that writhed and spat and screamed.

hi swɑloʊd hɑɹɾ ən tʃɹaɪd tə ɛdʒ ɹɛɾ əweɪ, bʌt tʃɹiz stʊɾ ɑn ɛvɹi saɪd, ən tʃɹɛmbəld. ðə beɪ ɹoʊld ɪz aɪz, waɪts ʃoʊɪŋ ɔl ðə weɪ ɝaʊnd. ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf ɪn ə sɑləd nɑɾ ə hɔɹs flɛʃ əz ɛvɹiwʌn ɛls tʃɹaɪd tə də ðə seɪm əz hi.

He swallowed hard and tried to edge Red away, but trees stood on every side, and trembled. The bay rolled his eyes, whites showing all the way around. Rand found himself in a solid knot of horse flesh as everyone else tried to do the same as he.

"kip muvɪŋ," læn kəmændəd, dʒɹɔɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd. ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɔɹ stil-bækt ɡɔnləts naʊ, ən ɪz ɡɹeɪ-ɡɹin skeɪl tunɪk. "steɪ wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ." hi pʊl mændɑɹb ɝaʊnd, nɑt təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹi ən ɪts pɹeɪ, bʌɾ ɪn ði ʌðɝ dɝɛkʃən. wɪð ɪz kʌlɝ-ʃɪftɪŋ kloʊk, hi wɑz swɑloʊd baɪ ðə blaɪt bɪfɔɹ ðə blæk stæljən wɑz aʊɾ ə saɪt.

"Keep moving," Lan commanded, drawing his sword. The Warder wore steel-backed gauntlets now, and his gray-green scale tunic. "Stay with Moiraine Sedai." He pulled Mandarb around, not toward the tree and its prey, but in the other direction. With his color-shifting cloak, he was swallowed by the Blight before the black stallion was out of sight.

"kloʊs," mɔɪɹeɪn ɝdʒd. ʃi dɪd nɑt sloʊ hɝ waɪt mɛɹ, bʌt ʃi moʊʃən ði ʌðɝz tə hʌɾəl nɪɹɝ tə hɝ. "steɪ əz kloʊs əz jə kæn."

"Close," Moiraine urged. She did not slow her white mare, but she motioned the others to huddle nearer to her. "Stay as close as you can."

ə ɹɔɹ spɹæŋ ʌp fɹəm ðə dɝɛkʃən ðə wɔɹɾɝ hæd ɡɔn. ɪt biɾ ət ði ɛɹ, ən ðə tʃɹiz kwɪvɝd fɹəm ɪt, ən wən ɪt feɪɾəd əweɪ, ɪt sim tə ɛkoʊ stɪl. əɡɛn ðə ɹɔɹ keɪm, fɪld wɪð ɹeɪdʒ ən dɛθ.

A roar sprang up from the direction the Warder had gone. It beat at the air, and the trees quivered from it, and when it faded away, it seemed to echo still. Again the roar came, filled with rage and death.

"læn," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "hi - "

"Lan," Nynaeve said. "He - "

ði ɑfəl saʊn kʌɾ əɹ ɔf, bʌt ðəɹ wɑz ə nu noʊɾ ɪn ɪt. fɪɹ. əbɹʌpli ɪt wɑz ɡɔn.

The awful sound cut her off, but there was a new note in it. Fear. Abruptly it was gone.

"læn kən lʊk æftɝ hɪmsɛlf," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ɹaɪd, wɪzdəm."

"Lan can look after himself," Moiraine said. "Ride, Wisdom."

fɹəm aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz ðə wɔɹɾɝ əpɪɹd, hoʊldɪŋ ɪz sɔɹd wɛl klɪɹ ə hɪmsɛlf ən ɪz maʊnt. blæk blʌd steɪn ðə bleɪd, ən stim ɹoʊz fɹəm ɪt. kɛɹfəli, læn waɪp ðə bleɪd klin wɪð ə klɔθ i tʊk fɹəm ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz, ɪɡzæmɪnɪŋ ðə stil tə meɪk ʃʊɹ i hæd ɡɑɾən ɛvɹi spɑt. wən i dʒɹɑp ðə klɔθ, ɪt fɛl əpɑɹt bɪfɔɹ ɪt ɹitʃt ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ivən ðə fɹæɡməns dɪzɔlvɪŋ.

From out of the trees the Warder appeared, holding his sword well clear of himself and his mount. Black blood stained the blade, and steam rose from it. Carefully, Lan wiped the blade clean with a cloth he took from his saddlebags, examining the steel to make sure he had gotten every spot. When he dropped the cloth, it fell apart before it reached the ground, even the fragments dissolving.

saɪlənli ə mæsɪv bɑɾi lɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz ət ðɛm. ðə wɔɹɾɝ spʌn mændɑɹb, bʌɾ ivən əz ðə wɔɹhɔɹs ɹɪɹd, ɹɛɾi tə stʃɹaɪk wɪð stilʃɑd hʊvz, mæts æɹoʊ flæʃt, pɪɹsɪŋ ðə wʌn aɪ ɪn ə hɛd ðət simd moʊsli maʊθ ən tiθ. kɪkɪŋ ən skɹimɪŋ, ðə θɪŋ fɛl, wʌn baʊnd ʃɔɹɾ ə ðɛm. ɹænd stɛɹɾ əz ðeɪ hɝid pæst. stɪf hɛɹ laɪk lɔŋ bɹɪsəlz kʌvɝɾ ɪt, ən ɪt hæd tu mɛni lɛɡz, dʒɔɪnɪŋ ə bɑɾi əz bɪɡ əz ə bɛɹ əɾ ɑɾ æŋɡəlz. səm ə ðɛm ət list, ðoʊz kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ʌv ɪts bæk, hæd tə bi jusləs fəɹ wɔkɪŋ, bʌt ðə fɪŋɡɝ-lɔŋ klɔz ət ðɛɹ ɛnz tɔɹ ði ɝθ ɪn ɪts dɛθ æɡəni.

Silently a massive body leaped out of the trees at them. The Warder spun Mandarb, but even as the warhorse reared, ready to strike with steelshod hooves, Mat's arrow flashed, piercing the one eye in a head that seemed mostly mouth and teeth. Kicking and screaming, the thing fell, one bound short of them. Rand stared as they hurried past. Stiff hair like long bristles covered it, and it had too many legs, joining a body as big as a bear at odd angles. Some of them at least, those coming out of its back, had to be useless for walking, but the finger-long claws at their ends tore the earth in its death agony.

"ɡʊd ʃuɾɪŋ, ʃifɝɾɝ." lænz aɪz hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi fɝɡɑɾən wʌt wɑz daɪɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛm, ən wɝ sɝtʃɪŋ ðə fɔɹəst.

"Good shooting, sheepherder." Lan's eyes had already forgotten what was dying behind them, and were searching the forest.

mɔɪɹeɪn ʃʊk əɹ hɛd. "ɪt ʃəd nɑɾ əv bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə kʌm soʊ kloʊs tə wʌn u tʌtʃəz ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs."

Moiraine shook her head. "It should not have been willing to come so close to one who touches the True Source."

"eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd ðə blaɪt stɝz," læn sɛd. "pɝhæps ðə blaɪɾ ɔlsoʊ noʊz ə wɛb ɪz fɔɹmɪŋ ɪn ðə pæɾɝn."

"Agelmar said the Blight stirs," Lan said. "Perhaps the Blight also knows a Web is forming in the Pattern."

"hɝi." mɔɪɹeɪn dʌɡ hɝ hilz ɪndə ɑldibz flæŋks. "wi mʌst ɡɛɾ oʊvɝ ðə haɪ pæsəz kwɪkli."

"Hurry." Moiraine dug her heels into Aldieb's flanks. "We must get over the high passes quickly."

bʌɾ ivən əz ʃi spoʊk ðə blaɪt ɹoʊz əɡɛns ðɛm. tʃɹiz wɪpt ɪn, ɹitʃɪŋ fəɹ ðɛm, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn tʌtʃt ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs əɹ nɑt.

But even as she spoke the Blight rose against them. Trees whipped in, reaching for them, not caring if Moiraine touched the True Source or not.

ɹændz sɔɹd wɑz ɪn ɪz hænd; hi dɪd nɑt ɹɪmɛmbɝ ənʃiðɪŋ ɪt. hi stʃɹʌk aʊɾ əɡɛn ən əɡɛn, ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd slaɪsɪŋ θɹu kɝʌptɪd lɪmz. hʌŋɡɹi bɹæntʃəz dʒɝk bæk sɛvɝd, ɹaɪðɪŋ stʌmps - hi ɔlmoʊs θɔɾ i hɝɾ əm skɹim - bʌɾ ɔlweɪz mɔɹ keɪm, ɹɪəlɪŋ laɪk sneɪks, ətɛmptɪŋ tə snɛɹ ɪz ɑɹmz, hɪz weɪst, hɪz nɛk. tiθ bɛɹɾ ɪn ə ɹɪktəs snɑɹl, hi sɔt ðə vɔɪd, ən faʊn ɪɾ ɪn ðə stoʊni, stʌbɝn sɔɪl ə ðə tu ɹɪvɝz. "meɪnɛðɝən!" hi skɹim bæk ət ðə tʃɹiz tɪl ɪz θɹoʊɾ ætʃt. ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk stil flæʃt ɪn ðə stʃɹɛŋkθləs sʌnlaɪt. "meɪnɛðɝən! meɪnɛðɝən!"

Rand's sword was in his hand; he did not remember unsheathing it. He struck out again and again, the heron-mark blade slicing through corrupted limbs. Hungry branches jerked back severed, writhing stumps - he almost thought he heard them scream - but always more came, wriggling like snakes, attempting to snare his arms, his waist, his neck. Teeth bared in a rictus snarl, he sought the void, and found it in the stony, stubborn soil of the Two Rivers. "Manetheren!" He screamed back at the trees till his throat ached. The heron-mark steel flashed in the strengthless sunlight. "Manetheren! Manetheren!"

stændɪŋ ɪn ɪz stɝəps, mæt sɛn æɹoʊ æftɝ æɹoʊ flæʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə fɔɹəst, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ət dɪfɔɹmd ʃeɪps ðət snɑɹəld ən næʃt ʌnkaʊntɪd tiθ ɑn ðə ʃæfs ðət kɪl ðɛm, bɪɾ ət ðə klɔd fɔɹmz faɪɾɪŋ tə ɡɛɾ oʊvɝ ðɛm, tə ɹitʃ ðə maʊntəd fɪɡjɝz. mæt, tu, wɑz lɔs tə ðə pɹɛzənt. "kæɹɑi ən kɑldəzɑɹ!" hi ʃaʊɾəd əz i dʒɹu flɛtʃɪŋz tə tʃik ən lust. "kæɹɑi ən ɛlɪsɑnd! æl ɛlɪsɑnd! mɔɹdɛɹoʊ dɑɡeɪn pɑz dunti kwbɪjɑɹ! æl ɛlɪsɑnd!"

Standing in his stirrups, Mat sent arrow after arrow flashing into the forest, striking at deformed shapes that snarled and gnashed uncounted teeth on the shafts that killed them, bit at the clawed forms fighting to get over them, to reach the mounted figures. Mat, too, was lost to the present. "Carai an Caldazar!" he shouted as he drew fletchings to cheek and loosed. "Carai an Ellisande! Al Ellisande! Mordero daghain pas duente cuebiyar! Al Ellisande!"

pɛɹɪn ɔlsoʊ stʊɾ ɪn ɪz stɝəps, saɪlən ən ɡɹɪm. hi hæd teɪkən ðə lɛd, ən ɪz æks huɾ ə pæθ θɹu fɔɹəst ən faʊl flɛʃ əlaɪk, wɪtʃɛvɝ keɪm bɪfɔɹ hɪm. fleɪlɪŋ tʃɹiz ən haʊlɪŋ θɪŋz ʃaɪd fɹəm ðə stɑki æksəmən, ʃaɪɪŋ əz mʌtʃ fɹəm ðə fɪɹs ɡoʊldən aɪz əz fɹəm ðə wɪslɪŋ æks. hi fɔɹst ɪz hɔɹs fɔɹwɝd, stɛp baɪ dɪtɝmən stɛp.

Perrin also stood in his stirrups, silent and grim. He had taken the lead, and his axe hewed a path through forest and foul flesh alike, whichever came before him. Flailing trees and howling things shied from the stocky axeman, shying as much from the fierce golden eyes as from the whistling axe. He forced his horse forward, step by determined step.

faɪɝbɔlz stʃɹik fɹəm mɔɪɹeɪnz hænz, ən wɛɹ ðeɪ stʃɹʌk, ə ɹaɪðɪŋ tʃɹi bɪkeɪm ə tɔɹtʃ, ə tuθt ʃeɪp ʃɹikt ən bit wɪð hjumən hænz, ɹɛn ɪts oʊn fleɪmɪŋ flɛʃ wɪð fɪɹs klɔz əntɪl ɪt daɪd.

Fireballs streaked from Moiraine's hands, and where they struck, a writhing tree became a torch, a toothed shape shrieked and beat with human hands, rent its own flaming flesh with fierce claws until it died.

əɡɛn ən əɡɛn ðə wɔɹɾɝ tʊk mændɑɹb ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz, hɪz bleɪɾ ən ɡɔnləts dʒɹɪpɪŋ wɪð blʌd ðət bʌbəld ən stimd. wən i keɪm bæk naʊ, mɔɹ ɔfən ðən nɑt ðəɹ wɝ ɡæʃəz ɪn ɪz ɑɹmɝ, bliɾɪŋ ɡæʃəz ɪn ɪz flɛʃ, ən ɪz wɔɹhɔɹs stʌmbəld ən blɛd, tu. itʃ taɪm ði ɛɛs sədaɪ pɔz tə leɪ hɝ hænz ɑn ðə wunz, ən wən ʃi tʊk əm əweɪ, oʊnli ðə blʌd wɑz lɛft ɑn ənmɑɹk flɛʃ.

Again and again the Warder took Mandarb into the trees, his blade and gauntlets dripping with blood that bubbled and steamed. When he came back now, more often than not there were gashes in his armor, bleeding gashes in his flesh, and his warhorse stumbled and bled, too. Each time the Aes Sedai paused to lay her hands on the wounds, and when she took them away, only the blood was left on unmarked flesh.

"aɪ laɪt sɪɡnəl faɪɝz fəɹ ðə hæfmən," ʃi sɛd bɪɾɝli. "pɹɛs ɑn. pɹɛs ɑn!" ðeɪ meɪd ðɛɹ weɪ wʌn sloʊ peɪs əɾ ə taɪm.

"I light signal fires for the Halfmen," she said bitterly. "Press on. Press on!" They made their way one slow pace at a time.

ɪf ðə tʃɹiz hæd nɑt stʃɹʌk ɪndə ðə mæs ʌv ətækɪŋ flɛʃ əz mʌtʃ əz ət ðə hjumənz, ɪf ðə kɹitʃɝz, noʊ tu əlaɪk, hæd nɑt fɔt ðə tʃɹiz ən wʌn ənʌðɝ əz mʌtʃ əz tə ɹitʃ ðɛm, ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wʊɾə bɪn oʊvɝwɛlmd. hi wɑz nɑt sɝɾən ɪt wəd nɑt hæpən stɪl. ðən ə fluɾɪŋ kɹaɪ ɝoʊz bɪhaɪn ðɛm. dɪstən ən θɪn, ɪt kʌt θɹu ðə snɑɹlɪŋ fɹəm ðə dɛnəzənz ə ðə blaɪɾ ɝaʊn ðɛm.

If the trees had not struck into the mass of attacking flesh as much as at the humans, if the creatures, no two alike, had not fought the trees and one another as much as to reach them, Rand was sure they would have been overwhelmed. He was not certain it would not happen still. Then a fluting cry arose behind them. Distant and thin, it cut through the snarling from the denizens of the Blight around them.

ɪn ən ɪnstən ðə snɑɹlɪŋ sist, əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn slaɪst ɔf wɪð ə naɪf. ði ətækɪŋ ʃeɪps fɹoʊz; ðə tʃɹiz wɛn stɪl. əz sʌɾənli əz ðə θɪŋz wɪð lɛɡz hæɾ əpɪɹd, ðeɪ mɛltəɾ əweɪ, vænɪʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə twɪstəd fɔɹəst.

In an instant the snarling ceased, as if it had been sliced off with a knife. The attacking shapes froze; the trees went still. As suddenly as the things with legs had appeared, they melted away, vanishing into the twisted forest.

ðə ɹiɾi ʃɹɪl keɪm əɡɛn, laɪk ə kɹækt ʃɛpɝdz paɪps, ən wɑz ænsɝɾ ɪn kaɪn baɪ ə kɔɹəs. hæf ə dʌzən, sɪŋɪŋ əmʌŋ ðɛmsɛlvz, fɑɹ bɪhaɪnd.

The reedy shrill came again, like a cracked shepherd's pipes, and was answered in kind by a chorus. Half a dozen, singing among themselves, far behind.

"wɝmz," læn sɛd ɡɹɪmli, bɹɪŋɪŋ ə moʊn fɹəm lɔɪəl. "ðeɪv ɡɪvən əs ə ɹɛspɪt, ɪf wɪv taɪm tə juz ɪt." hɪz aɪz wɝ mi sʊɹɪŋ ðə dɪstəns jɛt tə ðə maʊntənz. "fju θɪŋz ɪn ðə blaɪt wɪl feɪs ə wɝm, kən ɪt bi əvɔɪɾəd." hi dʌɡ hɪz hilz ɪndə mændɑɹbz flæŋks. "ɹaɪd!" ðə hoʊl pɑɹɾi plʌnʒd æftɝ hɪm, θɹu ə blaɪt ðət sʌɾənli sim tʃɹuli dɛd, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə paɪpɪŋ bɪhaɪnd.

"Worms," Lan said grimly, bringing a moan from Loial. "They've given us a respite, if we have time to use it." His eyes were mea suring the distance yet to the mountains. "Few things in the Blight will face a Worm, can it be avoided." He dug his heels into Mandarb's flanks. "Ride!" The whole party plunged after him, through a Blight that suddenly seemed truly dead, except for the piping behind.

"ðeɪ wɝ skɛɹɾ ɔf baɪ wɝmz?" mæt sɛɾ ɪnkɹɛdʒjələsli. hi wɑz baʊnsɪŋ ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə slɪŋ ɪz baʊ əkɹɔs ɪz bæk.

"They were scared off by worms?" Mat said incredulously. He was bouncing in his saddle, trying to sling his bow across his back.

"eɪ wɝm" - ðəɹ wɑz ə ʃɑɹp dɪfɝəns ɪn ðə weɪ ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛɾ ɪt fɹəm ðə weɪ mæt hæd - "kæn kɪl ə feɪd, ɪf ðə feɪd hæzən ðə dɑɹk wʌnz oʊn lʌk wɪð ɪt. wɪv ən ɪntaɪɝ pæk ɑn əɹ tʃɹeɪl. ɹaɪd! ɹaɪd!" ðə dɑɹk piks wɝ kloʊsɝ naʊ. ən aʊɝ, ɹænd ɛstəmeɪɾəd, ət ðə peɪs ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑz sɛɾɪŋ.

"A Worm" - there was a sharp difference in the way the Warder said it from the way Mat had - "can kill a Fade, if the Fade hasn't the Dark One's own luck with it. We have an entire pack on our trail. Ride! Ride!" The dark peaks were closer now. An hour, Rand estimated, at the pace the Warder was setting.

"woʊn ðə wɝmz fɑloʊ əs ɪndə ðə maʊntənz?" ɛɡwin æsk bɹɛθləsli, ən læn ɡeɪv ə ʃɑɹp læf.

"Won't the Worms follow us into the mountains?" Egwene asked breathlessly, and Lan gave a sharp laugh.

"ðeɪ woʊnt. wɝmz ɑɹ əfɹeɪɾ ʌv wʌt laɪvz ɪn ðə haɪ pæsəz." lɔɪəl moʊn əɡɛn.

"They won't. Worms are afraid of what lives in the high passes." Loial moaned again.

ɹænd wɪʃt ði oʊɡiɝ wəd stɑp duɪŋ ðæt. hi wɑz wɛl əwɛɹ ðət lɔɪəl nu mɔɹ əbaʊt ðə blaɪt ðən ɛni ʌv əm ɪksɛp læn, ivən ɪf ɪt wɑz fɹəm ɹiɾɪŋ bʊks ɪn ðə seɪfti ʌv ə stɛɾɪŋ. bʌt waɪ dʌz i hæv tə kip ɹimaɪndɪŋ mi ðət ðɛɹz wɝs jɛt ðən wiv sin?

Rand wished the Ogier would stop doing that. He was well aware that Loial knew more about the Blight than any of them except Lan, even if it was from reading books in the safety of a stedding. But why does he have to keep reminding me that there's worse yet than we've seen?

ðə blaɪt floʊd pæst, widz ən ɡɹæsəz splæʃɪŋ ɹɑɾən ʌndɝ ɡæləpɪŋ hʊvz. tʃɹiz ə ðə kaɪnz ðət hæɾ ɝliɝ ətæk dɪd nɑt soʊ mʌtʃ əz twɪtʃ ivən wən ðeɪ ɹoʊd dɝɛkli ʌndɝ ðə twɪstəd bɹæntʃəz. ðə maʊntənz ə dum fɪl ðə skaɪ əhɛd, blæk ən blik, ən ɔlmoʊs nɪɹ ɪnʌf tə tʌtʃ, ɪt simd. ðə paɪpɪŋ keɪm boʊθ ʃɑɹp ən klɪɹ, ən ðəɹ wɝ skwɪʃɪŋ saʊnz bɪhaɪn ðɛm, laʊɾɝ ðən ðə θɪŋz kɹʌʃt ʌndɝ hʊvz. tu laʊd, əz ɪf hæf-dəkeɪd tʃɹiz wɝ biɪŋ kɹʌʃt baɪ hjudʒ bɑɾiz slɪðɝɪŋ oʊvɝ ðɛm. tu nɪɹ. ɹænd lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ. bæk ðəɹ tʃɹitɑps wɪpt ən wɛn daʊn laɪk ɡɹæs. ðə læn bɪɡæn sloʊpɪŋ ʌpwɝd, təwɔɹd ðə maʊntənz, tɪltɪŋ ɪnʌf soʊ ðəɾ i nu ðeɪ wɝ klaɪmɪŋ.

The Blight flowed past, weeds and grasses splashing rotten under galloping hooves. Trees of the kinds that had earlier attacked did not so much as twitch even when they rode directly under the twisted branches. The Mountains of Dhoom filled the sky ahead, black and bleak, and almost near enough to touch, it seemed. The piping came both sharp and clear, and there were squishing sounds behind them, louder than the things crushed under hooves. Too loud, as if half-decayed trees were being crushed by huge bodies slithering over them. Too near. Rand looked over his shoulder. Back there treetops whipped and went down like grass. The land began sloping upward, toward the mountains, tilting enough so that he knew they were climbing.

"wi ɑɹ nɑt gɑnə meɪk ɪt," læn ənaʊnst. hi dɪd nɑt sloʊ mændɑɹbz ɡæləp, bʌɾ ɪz sɔɹd wɑz sʌɾənli ɪn ɪz hæn əɡɛn. "wɑtʃ jɝsɛlf ɪn ðə haɪ pæsəz, mɔɪɹeɪn, ən jəl ɡɛt θɹu."

"We are not going to make it," Lan announced. He did not slow Mandarb's gallop, but his sword was suddenly in his hand again. "Watch yourself in the high passes, Moiraine, and you'll get through."

"noʊ, læn!" nɪneɪiv kɔld.

"No, Lan!" Nynaeve called.

"bi kwaɪət, ɡɝl! læn, ivən jə kænɑt stɑp ə wɝmpæk. əl nɑɾ əv ɪt. əl nid jə fəɹ ði aɪ."

"Be quiet, girl! Lan, even you cannot stop a Wormpack. I will not have it. I will need you for the Eye."

"æɹoʊz," mæt kɔl bɹɛθləsli.

"Arrows," Mat called breathlessly.

"ðə wɝmz wʊdn ivən fil ðɛm," ðə wɔɹɾɝ ʃaʊɾəd. "ðeɪ mʌs bi kʌt tə pisəz. doʊn fil mʌtʃ bʌt hʌŋɡɝ. səmtaɪmz fɪɹ."

"The Worms wouldn't even feel them," the Warder shouted. "They must be cut to pieces. Don't feel much but hunger. Sometimes fear."

klɪŋɪŋ tə hɪz sæɾəl wɪð ə dɛθɡɹɪp, ɹænd ʃɹʌɡd, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə lusən ðə taɪtnəs ɪn ɪz ʃoʊldɝz. hɪz hoʊl tʃɛs fɛl taɪt, əntɪl i kəd hɑɹdli bɹið, ən ɪz skɪn stʌŋ ɪn hɑt pɪnpɹɪks. ðə blaɪt hæd tɝn tə fʊthɪlz. hi kəd si ðə ɹut ðeɪ mʌs klaɪm wʌns ðeɪ ɹitʃt ðə maʊntənz, ðə twɪstɪŋ pæθ ən ðə haɪ pæs bɪɑnd, laɪk ən æks bloʊ klivɪŋ ɪndə ðə blæk stoʊn. laɪt, wʌts ʌp əhɛd ðət kən skɛɹ wʌts bɪhaɪnd? laɪt hɛlp mi, aɪv nɛvɝ bɪn soʊ əfɹeɪd. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə ɡoʊ ɛni fɝðɝ. noʊ fɝðɝ! sikɪŋ ðə fleɪm ən ðə vɔɪd, hi ɹeɪld ət hɪmsɛlf. ful! jə fɹaɪɾənd, kaʊɝdli ful! jə kæn steɪ hɪɹ, ən jə kænt ɡoʊ bæk. ɑɹ jə gɑnə liv ɛɡwin tə feɪs ɪɾ əloʊn? ðə vɔɪɾ ɪluɾɪd hɪm, fɔɹmɪŋ, ðən ʃɪvɝɪŋ ɪndə ə θaʊzən pɔɪns ə laɪt, ɹeɪ-fɔɹmɪŋ ən ʃæɾɝɪŋ əɡɛn, itʃ pɔɪn bɝnɪŋ ɪndə hɪz boʊnz əntɪl i kwɪvɝd wɪð ðə peɪn ən θɔɾ i mʌs bɝst oʊpən. laɪt hɛlp mi, aɪ kænt ɡoʊ ɑn. laɪt hɛlp mi!

Clinging to his saddle with a deathgrip, Rand shrugged, trying to loosen the tightness in his shoulders. His whole chest felt tight, until he could hardly breathe, and his skin stung in hot pinpricks. The Blight had turned to foothills. He could see the route they must climb once they reached the mountains, the twisting path and the high pass beyond, like an axe blow cleaving into the black stone. Light, what's up ahead that can scare what's behind? Light help me, I've never been so afraid. I don't want to go any further. No further! Seeking the flame and the void, he railed at himself. Fool! You frightened, cowardly fool! You can't stay here, and you can't go back. Are you going to leave Egwene to face it alone? The void eluded him, forming, then shivering into a thousand points of light, re-forming and shattering again, each point burning into his bones until he quivered with the pain and thought he must burst open. Light help me, I can't go on. Light help me!

hi wɑz ɡæðɝɪŋ ðə beɪz ɹeɪnz tə tɝn bæk, tə feɪs ðə wɝmz əɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɹæðɝ ðən wʌt leɪ əhɛd, wən ðə neɪtʃɝ ə ðə læn tʃeɪnʒd. bɪtwin wʌn sloʊp ʌv ə hɪl ən ðə nɛkst, bɪtwin kɹɛst ən pik, ðə blaɪt wɑz ɡɔn.

He was gathering the bay's reins to turn back, to face the Worms or anything rather than what lay ahead, when the nature of the land changed. Between one slope of a hill and the next, between crest and peak, the Blight was gone.

ɡɹin livz kʌvɝd pisfəli spɹɛɾɪŋ bɹæntʃəz. waɪldflaʊɹz meɪɾ ə kɑɹpəɾ ə bɹaɪt pætʃəz ɪn ɡɹæsəz stɝd baɪ ə swit spɹɪŋ bɹiz. bʌɾɝflaɪz flʌɾɝd fɹəm blɑsəm tə blɑsəm, wɪð bʌzɪŋ biz, ən bɝdz tʃɹɪl ðɛɹ sɔŋz.

Green leaves covered peacefully spreading branches. Wildflowers made a carpet of bright patches in grasses stirred by a sweet spring breeze. Butterflies fluttered from blossom to blossom, with buzzing bees, and birds trilled their songs.

ɡeɪpɪŋ, hi ɡæləpt ɑn, əntɪl i sʌɾənli ɹilaɪz ðət mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn ən lɔɪəl hæd stɑpt, ði ʌðɝz, tu. sloʊli hi dʒɹu ɹeɪn, hɪz feɪs fɹoʊzən ɪn əstɑnɪʃmənt. ɛɡwinz aɪz wɝ əbaʊt tə kʌm aʊɾ ə hɝ hɛd, ən nɪneɪivz dʒɔ hæd dʒɹɑpt.

Gaping, he galloped on, until he suddenly realized that Moiraine and Lan and Loial had stopped, the others, too. Slowly he drew rein, his face frozen in astonishment. Egwene's eyes were about to come out of her head, and Nynaeve's jaw had dropped.

"wi hæv ɹitʃt seɪfti," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ðɪs ɪz ðə ɡɹin mænz pleɪs, ən ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld ɪz hɪɹ. nʌθɪŋ ə ðə blaɪt kən ɛntɝ hɪɹ."

"We have reached safety," Moiraine said. "This is the Green Man's place, and the Eye of the World is here. Nothing of the Blight can enter here."

"aɪ θɔɾ ɪt wɑz ɑn ði ʌðɝ saɪɾ ə ðə maʊntənz," ɹænd mʌmbəld. hi kəd stɪl si ðə piks fɪlɪŋ ðə nɔɹðɝn hɝaɪzən, ən ðə haɪ pæsəz. "ju sɛɾ ɪt wɑz ɔlweɪz bɪɑn ðə pæsəz."

"I thought it was on the other side of the mountains," Rand mumbled. He could still see the peaks filling the northern horizon, and the high passes. "You said it was always beyond the passes."

"ðɪs pleɪs," sɛɾ ə dip vɔɪs fɹəm ðə tʃɹiz, "ɪz ɔlweɪz wɛɹ ɪɾ ɪz. ɔl ðət tʃeɪnʒəz ɪz wɛɹ ðoʊz u niɾ ɪɾ ɑɹ."

"This place," said a deep voice from the trees, "is always where it is. All that changes is where those who need it are."

ə fɪɡjɝ stɛpt aʊɾ ə ðə foʊlɪdʒ, ə mæn-ʃeɪp əz mʌtʃ bɪɡɝ ðən lɔɪəl əz ði oʊɡiɝ wɑz bɪɡɝ ðən ɹænd. ə mæn-ʃeɪp ʌv woʊvən vaɪnz ən livz, ɡɹin ən ɡɹoʊɪŋ. hɪz hɛɹ wɑz ɡɹæs, floʊɪŋ tə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz; hɪz aɪz, hjudʒ heɪzəlnʌts; hɪz fɪŋɡɝneɪlz, eɪkɔɹnz. ɡɹin livz meɪɾ ɪz tunɪk ən tʃɹaʊzɝz; simləs bɑɹk, hɪz buts. bʌɾɝflaɪz swɝld ɝaʊn hɪm, laɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz fɪŋɡɝz, hɪz ʃoʊldɝz, hɪz feɪs. oʊnli wʌn θɪŋ spɔɪl ðə vɝɾənt pɝfɛkʃən. ə dip fɪʃɝ ɹæn ʌp ɪz tʃik ən tɛmpəl əkɹɔs ðə tɑp ə hɪz hɛd, ən ɪn ðət ðə vaɪnz wɝ bɹaʊn ən wɪðɝd.

A figure stepped out of the foliage, a man-shape as much bigger than Loial as the Ogier was bigger than Rand. A man-shape of woven vines and leaves, green and growing. His hair was grass, flowing to his shoulders; his eyes, huge hazelnuts; his fingernails, acorns. Green leaves made his tunic and trousers; seamless bark, his boots. Butterflies swirled around him, lighting on his fingers, his shoulders, his face. Only one thing spoiled the verdant perfection. A deep fissure ran up his cheek and temple across the top of his head, and in that the vines were brown and withered.

"ðə ɡɹin mæn," ɛɡwin wɪspɝd, ən ðə skɑɹd feɪs smaɪld. fəɹ ə moʊmən ɪt simd əz ɪf ðə bɝdz sæŋ laʊɾɝ.

"The Green Man," Egwene whispered, and the scarred face smiled. For a moment it seemed as if the birds sang louder.

"ʌv kɔɹs aɪ æm. hu ɛls wəd bi hɪɹ?" ðə heɪzəlnʌɾ aɪz ɹəɡɑɹɾəd lɔɪəl. "ɪɾ ɪz ɡʊd tə si ju, lɪɾəl bɹʌðɝ. ɪn ðə pæst, mɛni ʌv jə keɪm tə vɪzət mi, bʌt fju ʌv ɹisən deɪz."

"Of course I am. Who else would be here?" The hazelnut eyes regarded Loial. "It is good to see you, little brother. In the past, many of you came to visit me, but few of recent days."

lɔɪəl skɹæmbəl daʊn fɹəm ɪz bɪɡ hɔɹs ən baʊd fɔɹməli. "ju ɑnɝ mi, tʃɹibɹəðɝ. tsɪŋɡʌ mɑ tʃɑʃə, tɪŋʃən."

Loial scrambled down from his big horse and bowed formally. "You honor me, Treebrother. Tsingu ma choshih, T'ingshen."

smaɪlɪŋ, ðə ɡɹin mæn pʊɾ ən ɑɹm ɝaʊn ði oʊɡiɝz ʃoʊldɝz. əlɔŋsaɪd lɔɪəl, hi lʊk laɪk ə mæn bɪsaɪɾ ə bɔɪ. "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ ɑnɝɪŋ, lɪɾəl bɹʌðɝ. wɪl sɪŋ tʃɹi sɔŋz təɡɛðɝ, ən ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə ɡɹeɪt tʃɹiz, ən ðə stɛɾɪŋ, ən hoʊl ðə lɔŋɪŋ ət beɪ." hi stʌɾid ði ʌðɝz, dʒʌs naʊ ɡɛɾɪŋ daʊn fɹəm ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz, ən ɪz aɪz lɪɾ ɑn pɛɹɪn. "eɪ wʊlfbɹəðɝ! də ði oʊl taɪmz tʃɹuli wɔk əɡɛn ðɛn?"

Smiling, the Green Man put an arm around the Ogier's shoulders. Alongside Loial, he looked like a man beside a boy. "There is no honoring, little brother. We will sing Tree Songs together, and remember the Great Trees, and the stedding, and hold the Longing at bay." He studied the others, just now getting down from their horses, and his eyes lit on Perrin. "A Wolfbrother! Do the old times truly walk again then?"

ɹænd stɛɹɾ ət pɛɹɪn. fəɹ ɪz pɑɹt, pɛɹɪn tɝn ɪz hɔɹs soʊ ɪt wɑz bɪtwin ɪm ən ðə ɡɹin mæn, ən bɛn tə tʃɛk ðə ɡɝθ. ɹænd wɑz ʃʊɹ i dʒʌst wɑntəd tə əvɔɪd ðə ɡɹin mænz sɝtʃɪŋ ɡeɪz. sʌɾənli ðə ɡɹin mæn spoʊk tə ɹænd.

Rand stared at Perrin. For his part, Perrin turned his horse so it was between him and the Green Man, and bent to check the girth. Rand was sure he just wanted to avoid the Green Man's searching gaze. Suddenly the Green Man spoke to Rand.

"stʃɹeɪnʒ kloʊðz jə wɛɹ, tʃaɪld ə ðə dʒɹæɡən. hæz ðə wil tɝn soʊ fɑɹ? də ðə pipəl ə ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹɪtɝn tə ðə fɝs kʌvənənt? bʌt jə wɛɹ ə sɔɹd. ðəɾ ɪz niðɝ naʊ nɔɹ ðɛn."

"Strange clothes you wear, Child of the Dragon. Has the Wheel turned so far? Do the People of the Dragon return to the first Covenant? But you wear a sword. That is neither now nor then."

ɹænd hæd tə wɝk mɔɪstʃɝ ɪn ɪz maʊθ bɪfɔɹ i kəd spik. "aɪ doʊnt noʊ wʌt jəɹ tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt. wʌt dʒju min?"

Rand had to work moisture in his mouth before he could speak. "I don't know what you're talking about. What do you mean?"

ðə ɡɹin mæn tʌtʃt ðə bɹaʊn skɑɹ əkɹɔs ɪz hɛd. fəɹ ə moʊmən i sim kənfjuzd. "aɪ . . . kænɑt seɪ. maɪ mɛmɹiz ɑɹ tɔɹn ən ɔfən fliɾɪŋ, ən mʌtʃ ʌv wʌt ɹɪmeɪnz ɪz laɪk livz vɪzəɾəd baɪ kæɾəpɪlɝz. jɛt, aɪm ʃʊɹ. . . . noʊ, ɪts ɡɔn. bʌt jə ɑɹ wɛlkəm hɪɹ. ju, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ, ɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ə sɝpɹaɪz. wən ðɪs pleɪs wɑz meɪd, ɪt wɑz meɪd soʊ ðət nʌn kəd faɪn ɪt twaɪs. haʊ hæv jə kʌm hɪɹ?"

The Green Man touched the brown scar across his head. For a moment he seemed confused. "I . . . cannot say. My memories are torn and often fleeting, and much of what remains is like leaves visited by caterpillars. Yet, I am sure. . . . No, it is gone. But you are welcome here. You, Moiraine Sedai, are more than a surprise. When this place was made, it was made so that none could find it twice. How have you come here?"

"nid," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "maɪ nid, ðə wɝlz nid. moʊst ʌv ɔl ɪz ðə wɝlz nid. wɪv kʌm tə si ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld."

"Need," Moiraine replied. "My need, the world's need. Most of all is the world's need. We have come to see the Eye of the World."

ðə ɡɹin mæn saɪd, ðə wɪn saɪɪŋ θɹu θɪk-lif bɹæntʃəz. "ðɛn ɪts kʌm əɡɛn. ðət mɛmɹi ɹɪmeɪnz hoʊl. ðə dɑɹk wʌn stɝz. aɪ hæv fɪɹɾ ɪt. ɛvɹi tɝnɪŋ ə jɪɹz, ðə blaɪt stʃɹaɪvz hɑɹɾɝ tə kʌm ɪnsaɪd, ən ðɪs tɝn ðə stʃɹʌɡəl tə kip ɪɾ aʊɾ əz bɪn ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ɛvɝ sɪns ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ. kʌm, əl teɪk ju."

The Green Man sighed, the wind sighing through thick-leafed branches. "Then it has come again. That memory remains whole. The Dark One stirs. I have feared it. Every turning of years, the Blight strives harder to come inside, and this turn the struggle to keep it out has been greater than ever since the beginning. Come, I will take you."


tʃæptɝ fɪfti


CHAPTER 50

miɾɪŋz ət ði aɪ


Meetings at the Eye

liɾɪŋ ðə beɪ, ɹænd fɑloʊd ðə ɡɹin mæn wɪð ði ʌðɝ ɛmənz fildɝz, ɔl stɛɹɪŋ əz ɪf ðeɪ kəd nɑt dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ tə lʊk ət ðə ɡɹin mæn əɹ ðə fɔɹəst. ðə ɡɹin mæn wɑz ə lɛdʒənd, ʌv kɔɹs, wɪð stɔɹiz toʊld əbaʊt hɪm, ən ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf, ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛvɹi faɪɝpleɪs ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz, ən nɑt dʒʌs fəɹ ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. bʌɾ æftɝ ðə blaɪt, ðə tʃɹiz ən flaʊɝz wʊɾə bɪn ə wʌndɝ ə nɔɹmæləɾi ivən ɪf ðə ɹɛst ə ðə wɝld wɑz nɑt stɪl tʃɹæpt ɪn wɪntɝ.

Leading the bay, Rand followed the Green Man with the other Emond's Fielders, all staring as if they could not decide whether to look at the Green Man or the forest. The Green Man was a legend, of course, with stories told about him, and the Tree of Life, in front of every fireplace in the Two Rivers, and not just for the children. But after the Blight, the trees and flowers would have been a wonder of normality even if the rest of the world was not still trapped in winter.

pɛɹɪn hʌŋ ə lɪɾəl tə ðə ɹɪɹ. wən ɹænd ɡlæns bæk, ðə bɪɡ, kɝli-hɛɹd juθ lʊkt əz ɪf i dɪd nɑt wɑnə hɪɹ ɛniθɪŋ ɛls ðə ɡɹin mæn hæd tə seɪ. hi kəɾ ʌndɝstæn ðæt. tʃaɪld ə ðə dʒɹæɡən. wɛɹəli hi wɑtʃt ðə ɡɹin mæn, wɔkɪŋ əhɛd wɪð mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn, bʌɾɝflaɪz sɝaʊndɪŋ ɪm ɪn ə klaʊɾ ə jɛloʊz ən ɹɛdz. wʌɾ i min? noʊ. aɪ doʊnt wɑnə noʊ.

Perrin hung a little to the rear. When Rand glanced back, the big, curly-haired youth looked as if he did not want to hear anything else the Green Man had to say. He could understand that. Child of the Dragon. Warily he watched the Green Man, walking ahead with Moiraine and Lan, butterflies surrounding him in a cloud of yellows and reds. What did he mean? No. I don't want to know.

ivən soʊ, hɪz stɛp fɛlt laɪɾɝ, hɪz lɛɡz spɹɪŋʒiɝ. ði ʌnizinəs stɪl leɪ ɪn ɪz ɡʌt, tʃɝnɪŋ ɪz stʌmək, bʌt ðə fɪɹ hæd bɪkʌm soʊ dɪfjuz ɪt maɪɾ əz wɛl bi ɡɔn. hi dɪd nɑt θɪŋk i kəɾ ɪkspɛk mɔɹ, nɑt wɪð ðə blaɪt hæf ə maɪl əweɪ, ivən ɪf mɔɪɹeɪn wɑz ɹaɪɾ əbaʊt nʌθɪŋ fɹəm ðə blaɪt biɪŋ eɪbəl tə ɛntɝ hɪɹ. ðə θaʊzənz ə bɝnɪŋ pɔɪns pɪɹsɪŋ ɪz boʊnz hæd wɪŋkt aʊt; ət ðə vɛɹi moʊmən i keɪm wɪðɪn ðə ɡɹin mænz doʊmeɪn, hi wɑz ʃʊɹ. ɪts ɪm ðət wɪŋkt əm aʊt, hi θɔt, ðə ɡɹin mæn, ən ðɪs pleɪs.

Even so, his step felt lighter, his legs springier. The uneasiness still lay in his gut, churning his stomach, but the fear had become so diffuse it might as well be gone. He did not think he could expect more, not with the Blight half a mile away, even if Moiraine was right about nothing from the Blight being able to enter here. The thousands of burning points piercing his bones had winked out; at the very moment he came within the Green Man's domain, he was sure. It's him that winked them out, he thought, the Green Man, and this place.

ɛɡwin fɛlt ɪt, ən nɪneɪiv, tu, ðə suðɪŋ pis, ðə kɑm ə bjuɾi. hi kəd tɛl. ðeɪ wɔɹ smɔl, sɝin smaɪlz, ən bɹʌʃt flaʊɝz wɪð ðɛɹ fɪŋɡɝz, pɔzɪŋ tə smɛl, ən bɹiðɪŋ dip.

Egwene felt it, and Nynaeve, too, the soothing peace, the calm of beauty. He could tell. They wore small, serene smiles, and brushed flowers with their fingers, pausing to smell, and breathing deep.

wən ðə ɡɹin mæn noʊɾəst, hi sɛd, "flaʊɝz ɑɹ mɛn tə ədɔɹn. ðə plæns əɹ hjumənz, ɪts mʌtʃ ðə seɪm. nʌn maɪnd, soʊ lɔŋ əz jə doʊn teɪk tu mɛni." ən i bɪɡæn plʌkɪŋ wʌn fɹəm ðɪs plæn ən wʌn fɹəm ðæt, nɛvɝ mɔɹ ðən tu fɹəm ɛni. sun nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin wɔɹ kæps ə blɑsəmz ɪn ðɛɹ hɛɹ, pɪŋk waɪldʒɹoʊz ən jɛloʊbɛl ən waɪt mɔɹnɪŋstɑɹ. ðə wɪzdəmz bɹeɪd simd ə ɡɑɹɾən ə pɪŋk ən waɪt tə hɝ weɪst. ivən mɔɪɹeɪn ɹəsivd ə peɪl ɡɑɹlən ə mɔɹnɪŋstɑɹ ɑn əɹ bɹaʊ, woʊvən soʊ dɛfli ðət ðə flaʊɝz stɪl sim tə bi ɡɹoʊɪŋ.

When the Green Man noticed, he said, "Flowers are meant to adorn. The plants or humans, it is much the same. None mind, so long as you don't take too many." And he began plucking one from this plant and one from that, never more than two from any. Soon Nynaeve and Egwene wore caps of blossoms in their hair, pink wildrose and yellowbell and white morningstar. The Wisdom's braid seemed a garden of pink and white to her waist. Even Moiraine received a pale garland of morningstar on her brow, woven so deftly that the flowers still seemed to be growing.

ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ðeɪ wɝ nɑt ɡɹoʊɪŋ. ðə ɡɹin mæn tɛndəɾ ɪz fɔɹəst ɡɑɹɾən əz i wɔkt, waɪl i tɔk sɔfli tə mɔɪɹeɪn, teɪkɪŋ kɛɹ ʌv wʌtɛvɝ niɾəd kɛɹ wɪθaʊt ɹɪli θɪŋkɪŋ əbaʊɾ ɪt. hɪz heɪzəlnʌɾ aɪz kɑɾ ə kɹʊkəd lɪm ɑn ə klaɪmɪŋ waɪldʒɹoʊz, fɔɹst ɪndə ən ɑkwɝɾ æŋɡəl baɪ ðə blɑsəm-kʌvɝd lɪm ʌv ən æpəl tʃɹi, ən i pɔzd, stɪl tɔkɪŋ, tə ɹʌn ɪz hæn əlɔŋ ðə bɛnd. ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪf ɪz aɪz wɝ pleɪɪŋ tʃɹɪks, əɹ ɪf θɔɹnz æktʃəli  dɪd bɛn aʊɾ ə ðə weɪ soʊ əz nɑt tə pɹɪk ðoʊz ɡɹin fɪŋɡɝz. wən ðə taʊɝɪŋ ʃeɪp ə ðə ɡɹin mæn muvd ɑn, ðə lɪm ɹæn stʃɹeɪɾ ən tʃɹu, spɹɛɾɪŋ ɹɛd pɛɾəlz əmʌŋ ðə waɪɾ ʌv æpəl blɑsəmz. hi bɛn tə kʌp wʌn hjudʒ hæn ɝaʊn ə taɪni sid laɪɪŋ ɑn ə pætʃ ə pɛbəlz, ən wən i stʃɹeɪɾənd, ə smɔl ʃut hæd ɹuts θɹu ðə ɹɑks tə ɡʊd sɔɪl.

Rand was not sure they were not growing. The Green Man tended his forest garden as he walked, while he talked softly to Moiraine, taking care of Whatever needed care without really thinking about it. His hazelnut eyes caught a crooked limb on a climbing wildrose, forced into an awkward angle by the blossom-covered limb of an apple tree, and he paused, still talking, to run his hand along the bend. Rand was not sure if his eyes were playing tricks, or if thorns actually did bend out of the way so as not to prick those green fingers. When the towering shape of the Green Man moved on, the limb ran straight and true, spreading red petals among the white of apple blossoms. He bent to cup one huge hand around a tiny seed lying on a patch of pebbles, and when he straightened, a small shoot had roots through the rocks to good soil.

"ɔl θɪŋz mʌst ɡɹoʊ wɛɹ ðeɪ ɑɹ, əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə pæɾɝn," hi ɪkspleɪn oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, əz ɪf əpɑlədʒaɪzɪŋ, "æn feɪs ðə tɝnɪŋ ə ðə wil, bʌt ðə kɹieɪɾɝ wɪl nɑt maɪn ɪf aɪ ɡɪv dʒʌst ə lɪɾəl hɛlp."

"All things must grow where they are, according to the Pattern," he explained over his shoulder, as if apologizing, "and face the turning of the Wheel, but the Creator will not mind if I give just a little help."

ɹænd lɛd ɹɛɾ ɝaʊn ðə ʃut, kɛɹfəl nɑt tə lɛt ðə beɪz hʊvz kɹʌʃ ɪt. ɪt dɪd nɑt sim ɹaɪt tə dɪstʃɹɔɪ wʌt ðə ɡɹin mæn hæd dʌn dʒʌs tə əvɔɪɾ ən ɛkstʃɹə stɛp. ɛɡwin smaɪld ət hɪm, wʌn ə hɝ sikɹət smaɪlz, ən tʌtʃt ɪz ɑɹm. ʃi wɑz soʊ pɹɪɾi, wɪð əɹ ənbaʊn hɛɹ fʊl ə flaʊɝz, ðəɾ i smaɪl bæk əɾ əɹ əntɪl ʃi blʌʃt ən loʊɝɾ əɹ aɪz. əl pɹətɛk ju, hi θɔt. wʌtɛvɝ ɛls hæpənz, əl si jə seɪf, aɪ swɛɹ ɪt.

Rand led Red around the shoot, careful not to let the bay's hooves crush it. It did not seem right to destroy what the Green Man had done just to avoid an extra step. Egwene smiled at him, one of her secret smiles, and touched his arm. She was so pretty, with her unbound hair full of flowers, that he smiled back at her until she blushed and lowered her eyes. I will protect you, he thought. Whatever else happens, I will see you safe, I swear it.

ɪndə ðə hɑɹɾ ə ðə spɹɪŋ fɔɹəs ðə ɡɹin mæn tʊk ðɛm, tə ən ɑɹtʃt oʊpənɪŋ ɪn ðə saɪɾ ʌv ə hɪl. ɪt wɑz ə sɪmpəl stoʊn ɑɹtʃ, tɔl ən waɪt, ən ɑn ðə kistoʊn wɑz ə sɝkəl hæv baɪ ə sɪnwəs laɪn, wʌn hæf ɹʌf, ði ʌðɝ smuð. ði eɪntʃən sɪmbəl ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ. ði oʊpənɪŋ ɪtsɛlf wɑz ʃæɾoʊd.

Into the heart of the spring forest the Green Man took them, to an arched opening in the side of a hill. It was a simple stone arch, tall and white, and on the keystone was a circle halved by a sinuous line, one half rough, the other smooth. The ancient symbol of Aes Sedai. The opening itself was shadowed.

fəɹ ə moʊmən ɛvɹiwʌn sɪmpli lʊkt ɪn saɪləns. ðən mɔɪɹeɪn ɹimuv ðə ɡɑɹlən fɹəm əɹ hɛɹ ən dʒɛnli hʌŋ ɪɾ ɑn ðə lɪm ʌv ə switbɛɹi bʊʃ bɪsaɪd ði ɑɹtʃ. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf əɹ muvmən ɹɪstɔɹd spitʃ.

For a moment everyone simply looked in silence. Then Moiraine removed the garland from her hair and gently hung it on the limb of a sweetberry bush beside the arch. It was as if her movement restored speech.

"ɪts ɪn ðɛɹ?" nɪneɪiv æskt. "wʌt wiv kʌm fɔɹ?"

"It's in there?" Nynaeve asked. "What we've come for?"

"aɪd ɹɪli laɪk tə si ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf," mæt sɛd, nɑt teɪkɪŋ ɪz aɪz ɔf ðə hæv sɝkəl əbʌv ðɛm. "wi kən weɪt ðət lɔŋ, kænt wi?"

"I'd really like to see the Tree of Life," Mat said, not taking his eyes off the halved circle above them. "We can wait that long, can't we?"

ðə ɡɹin mæn ɡeɪv ɹænd ən ɑd lʊk, ðən ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə ɪz nɑt hɪɹ. aɪ hæv nɑt ɹɛstəd bɪniθ ɪts ʌnʒəntəl bɹæntʃəz ɪn tu θaʊzən jɪɹz."

The Green Man gave Rand an odd look, then shook his head. "Avendesora is not here. I have not rested beneath its ungentle branches in two thousand years."

"ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf ɪz nɑt waɪ wi keɪm," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd fɝmli. ʃi dʒɛstʃɝd tə ði ɑɹtʃ. "ɪn ðɛɹ, ɪz."

"The Tree of Life is not why we came," Moiraine said firmly. She gestured to the arch. "In there, is."

"aɪ wɪl nɑt ɡoʊ ɪn wɪð ju," ðə ɡɹin mæn sɛd. ðə bʌɾɝflaɪz ɝaʊn ɪm swɝld əz ɪf ðeɪ ʃɛɹd səm ædʒəteɪʃən. "aɪ wɑz sɛt tə ɡɑɹɾ ɪt lɔŋ, lɔŋ əɡoʊ, bʌɾ ɪt meɪks mi ənizi tə kʌm tu kloʊs. aɪ fil maɪsɛlf biɪŋ ənmeɪd; maɪ ɛn ɪz lɪŋkt wɪð ɪt, sʌmhaʊ. aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðə meɪkɪŋ ʌv ɪt. səm ə ðə meɪkɪŋ. sʌm." hɪz heɪzəlnʌɾ aɪz stɛɹd, lɔst ɪn mɛmɹi, ən i fɪŋɡɝɾ ɪz skɑɹ. "ɪt wɑz ðə fɝs deɪz ə ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, wən ðə dʒɔɪ ʌv vɪktɝi oʊvɝ ðə dɑɹk wʌn tɝn bɪɾɝ wɪð ðə nɑlədʒ ðəɾ ɔl maɪt jɛt bi ʃæɾɝd baɪ ðə weɪɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. ə hʌnʒɹəd ə ðɛm meɪɾ ɪt, mɛn ən wɪmən təɡɛðɝ. ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst ɛɛs sədaɪ wɝks wɝ ɔlweɪz dʌn soʊ, dʒɔɪnɪŋ seɪɾɪn ən seɪaɪdɑɹ, əz ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ɪz dʒɔɪnd. ðeɪ daɪd, ɔl, tə meɪk ɪt pjʊɹ, waɪl ðə wɝld wɑz tɔɹn ɝaʊn ðɛm. noʊɪŋ ðeɪ wəd daɪ, ðeɪ tʃɑɹdʒ mi tə ɡɑɹɾ ɪɾ əɡɛns ðə nid tə kʌm. ɪt wɑz nɑt wʌɾ aɪ wɑz meɪd fɔɹ, bʌɾ ɔl wɑz bɹeɪkɪŋ əpɑɹt, ən ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn, ən aɪ wɑz ɔl ðeɪ hæd. ɪt wɑz nɑt wʌɾ aɪ wɑz meɪd fɔɹ, bʌɾ aɪ hæv kɛp ðə feɪθ." hi lʊk daʊn ət mɔɪɹeɪn, nɑɾɪŋ tə hɪmsɛlf. "aɪ hæv kɛp feɪθ, əntɪl ɪt wɑz niɾəd. ən naʊ ɪɾ ɛnz."

"I will not go in with you," the Green Man said. The butterflies around him swirled as if they shared some agitation. "I was set to guard it long, long ago, but it makes me uneasy to come too close. I feel myself being unmade; my end is linked with it, somehow. I remember the making of it. Some of the making. Some." His hazelnut eyes stared, lost in memory, and he fingered his scar. "It was the first days of the Breaking of the World, when the joy of victory over the Dark One turned bitter with the knowledge that all might yet be shattered by the weight of the Shadow. A hundred of them made it, men and women together. The greatest Aes Sedai works were always done so, joining saidin and saidar, as the True Source is joined. They died, all, to make it pure, while the world was torn around them. Knowing they would die, they charged me to guard it against the need to come. It was not what I was made for, but all was breaking apart, and they were alone, and I was all they had. It was not what I was made for, but I have kept the faith." He looked down at Moiraine, nodding to himself. "I have kept faith, until it was needed. And now it ends."

"ju hæv kɛp ðə feɪθ bɛɾɝ ðən moʊst ʌv əs u ɡeɪv jə ðə tʃɑɹdʒ," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd. "pɝhæps ɪɾəl nɑt kʌm əz bædli əz jə fɪɹ."

"You have kept the faith better than most of us who gave you the charge," the Aes Sedai said. "Perhaps it will not come as badly as you fear."

ðə skɑɹd, lifi hɛd ʃʊk sloʊli fɹəm saɪd tə saɪd. "aɪ noʊ ən ɛndɪŋ wən ɪt kʌmz, ɛɛs sədaɪ. əl faɪn ənʌðɝ pleɪs tə meɪk θɪŋz ɡɹoʊ." nʌtbɹoʊn aɪz swɛp sædli oʊvɝ ðə ɡɹin fɔɹəst. "ənʌðɝ pleɪs, pɝhæps. wən jə kʌm aʊt, əl si jə əɡɛn, ɪf ðəɹ ɪz taɪm." wɪð ðəɾ i stʃɹoʊɾ əweɪ, tʃɹeɪlɪŋ bʌɾɝflaɪz, bɪkʌmɪŋ wʌn wɪð ðə fɔɹəs mɔɹ kəmplitli ðən lænz kloʊk ɛvɝ kʊd.

The scarred, leafy head shook slowly from side to side. "I know an ending when it comes, Aes Sedai. I will find another place to make things grow." Nutbrown eyes swept sadly over the green forest. "Another place, perhaps. When you come out, I will see you again, if there is time." With that he strode away, trailing butterflies, becoming one with the forest more completely than Lan's cloak ever could.

"wʌt dɪɾ i min?" mæt dɪmændəd. "ɪf ðɛɹz taɪm?"

"What did he mean?" Mat demanded. "If there's time?"

"kʌm," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. ən ʃi stɛp θɹu ði ɑɹtʃ. læn wɛn əɾ əɹ hilz.

"Come," Moiraine said. And she stepped through the arch. Lan went at her heels.

ɹænd wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ wʌɾ i ɪkspɛktəd wən i fɑloʊd. ðə hɛɹ stɝɾ ənizəli ɑn ɪz ɑɹmz, ən ɹoʊz ɑn ðə bæk ə hɪz nɛk. bʌɾ ɪt wɑz oʊnli ə kɔɹəɾɝ, ɪts pɑlɪʃt wɔlz ɹaʊndəɾ oʊvɝhɛd laɪk ði ɑɹtʃ, waɪndɪŋ dʒɛnli daʊnwɝd. ðəɹ wɑz hɛdʒɹum ɪnʌf ən tə spɛɹ fəɹ lɔɪəl; ðəɹ wʊɾə bɪn ɹum ɪnʌf fəɹ ðə ɡɹin mæn. ðə smuð flɔɹ, slɪk tə ði aɪ laɪk ɔɪl sleɪt, jɛt sʌmhaʊ ɡeɪv ə ʃʊɹ fʊɾɪŋ. simləs, waɪt wɔlz ɡlɪɾɝd wɪð ʌnkaʊntɪd flɛks ɪn əntoʊl kʌlɝz, ɡɪvɪŋ ə loʊ, sɑf laɪɾ ivən æftɝ ðə sʌnlɪɾ ɑɹtʃweɪ vænɪʃt ɝaʊn ə kɝv bɪhaɪnd. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðə laɪt wɑz noʊ nætʃɹəl θɪŋ, bʌɾ i sɛnst ɪt wɑz bɪnaɪn, tu. ðən waɪ ɪz jəɹ skɪn stɪl kɹɔlɪŋ? daʊn ðeɪ wɛnt, ən daʊn.

Rand was not sure what he expected when he followed. The hair stirred uneasily on his arms, and rose on the back of his neck. But it was only a corridor, its polished walls rounded overhead like the arch, winding gently downward. There was headroom enough and to spare for Loial; there would have been room enough for the Green Man. The smooth floor, slick to the eye like oiled slate, yet somehow gave a sure footing. Seamless, white walls glittered with uncounted flecks in untold colors, giving a low, soft light even after the sunlit archway vanished around a curve behind. He was sure the light was no natural thing, but he sensed it was benign, too. Then why is your skin still crawling? Down they went, and down.

"ðɛɹ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛɾ ət læst, pɔɪntɪŋ. "əhɛd."

"There," Moiraine said at last, pointing. "Ahead."

ən ðə kɔɹəɾɝ oʊpən ɪndə ə væst, doʊm speɪs, ðə ɹʌf, lɪvɪŋ ɹɑk ʌv ɪts silɪŋ dɑɾəd wɪð klʌmps ʌv ɡloʊɪŋ kɹɪstəlz. bɪloʊ ɪt, ə pul tʊk ʌp ði ɪntaɪɝ kævɝn, ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə wɔkweɪ ɝaʊn ɪt, pɝhæps faɪv peɪsɪz waɪd. ɪn ði oʊvəl ʃeɪp ʌv ən aɪ, ðə pul wɑz laɪn əbaʊɾ ɪts ɹɪm wɪð ə loʊ, flæɾ ɛdʒɪŋ ə kɹɪstəlz ðət ɡloʊd wɪð ə dʌlɝ, jɛt fɪɹsɝ, laɪt ðən ðoʊz əbʌv. ɪts sɝfəs wɑz əz smuð əz ɡlæs ən əz klɪɹ əz ðə waɪnspɹɪŋ wɔɾɝ. ɹænd fɛlt əz ɪf ɪz aɪz kəd pɛnətʃɹeɪɾ ɪt fɝɛvɝ, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt si ɛni bɑɾəm tə ɪt.

And the corridor opened into a vast, domed space, the rough, living rock of its ceiling dotted with clumps of glowing crystals. Below it, a pool took up the entire cavern, except for the walkway around it, perhaps five paces wide. In the oval shape of an eye, the pool was lined about its rim with a low, flat edging of crystals that glowed with a duller, yet fiercer, light than those above. Its surface was as smooth as glass and as clear as the Winespring Water. Rand felt as if his eyes could penetrate it forever, but he could not see any bottom to it.

"ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd sɔfli bɪsaɪd hɪm.

"The Eye of the World," Moiraine said softly beside him.

əz i lʊkt ɝaʊn ɪn wʌndɝ, hi ɹilaɪz ðət ðə lɔŋ jɪɹz sɪns ðə meɪkɪŋ - θɹi θaʊzən ə ðɛm - hæd wɝk ðɛɹ weɪ waɪl noʊ wʌn keɪm. nɑɾ ɔl ðə kɹɪstəlz ɪn ðə doʊm ɡloʊd wɪð ðə seɪm ɪntɛnsəɾi. səm wɝ stʃɹɔŋɝ, səm wikɝ; səm flɪkɝd, ən ʌðɝz wɝ oʊnli fæsəɾɪd lʌmps tə spɑɹkəl ɪn ə kæptʃɝd laɪt. hæɾ ɔl ʃoʊn, ðə doʊm wʊɾə bɪn əz bɹaɪɾ əz nundeɪ, bʌt ðeɪ meɪɾ ɪɾ oʊnli leɪɾ æftɝnun, naʊ. dʌs koʊɾəd ðə wɔkweɪ, ən bɪts ə stoʊn ən ivən kɹɪstəl. lɔŋ jɪɹz weɪɾɪŋ, waɪl ðə wil tɝn ən ɡɹaʊnd.

As he looked around in wonder, he realized that the long years since the making - three thousand of them - had worked their way while no one came. Not all the crystals in the dome glowed with the same intensity. Some were stronger, some weaker; some flickered, and others were only faceted lumps to sparkle in a captured light. Had all shone, the dome would have been as bright as noonday, but they made it only late afternoon, now. Dust coated the walkway, and bits of stone and even crystal. Long years waiting, while the Wheel turned and ground.

"bʌt wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" mæt æskt ənizəli. "ðæt dʌzn lʊk laɪk ɛni wɔɾɝ aɪ ɛvɝ sɔ." hi kɪkt ə lʌmp ə dɑɹk stoʊn ðə saɪz ə hɪz fɪst oʊvɝ ði ɛdʒ. "ɪt - "

"But what is it?" Mat asked uneasily. "That doesn't look like any water I ever saw." He kicked a lump of dark stone the size of his fist over the edge. "It - "

ðə stoʊn stʃɹʌk ðə ɡlæsi sɝfəs ən slɪɾ ɪndə ðə pul wɪθaʊɾ ə splæʃ, əɹ soʊ mʌtʃ əz ə ɹɪpəl. əz ɪt sæŋk, ðə ɹɑk bɪɡæn tə swɛl, ɡɹoʊɪŋ ɛvɝ lɑɹdʒɝ, lɑɹdʒɝ ən mɔɹ ətɛnjueɪɾɪd, ə blɑb ðə saɪz ə hɪz hɛd ðət ɹænd kəɾ ɔlmoʊst si θɹu, ə feɪn blɝ əz waɪɾ əz ɪz ɑɹm wɑz lɔŋ. ðən ɪt wɑz ɡɔn. hi θɔɾ ɪz skɪn wəd kɹip ɹaɪɾ ɔf ɪz bɑɾi.

The stone struck the glassy surface and slid into the pool without a splash, or so much as a ripple. As it sank, the rock began to swell, growing ever larger, larger and more attenuated, a blob the size of his head that Rand could almost see through, a faint blur as wide as his arm was long. Then it was gone. He thought his skin would creep right off his body.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" hi dɪmændəd, ən wɑz ʃɑkt ət ðə hɔɹs hɑɹʃnəs ə hɪz oʊn vɔɪs.

"What is it?" he demanded, and was shocked at the hoarse harshness of his own voice.

"ɪt maɪt bi kɔl ði ɛsəns ə seɪɾɪn." ði ɛɛs sədaɪz wɝdz ɛkoʊd ɹaʊn ðə doʊm. "ði ɛsəns ə ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, ðə pjʊɹ ɛsəns ə ðə paʊɝ wildɪd baɪ mɛn bɪfɔɹ ðə taɪm ə mædnəs. ðə paʊɝ tə mɛn ðə sil ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən, əɹ tə bɹeɪk ɪɾ oʊpən kəmplitli."

"It might be called the essence of saidin." The Aes Sedai's words echoed round the dome. "The essence of the male half of the True Source, the pure essence of the Power wielded by men before the Time of Madness. The Power to mend the seal on the Dark One's prison, or to break it open completely."

"ðə laɪt ʃaɪn ɑn əs ən pɹətɛkt ʌs," nɪneɪiv wɪspɝd. ɛɡwin klʌtʃt əɹ əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə haɪd bɪhaɪn ðə wɪzdəm. ivən læn stɝɾ ənizəli, ðoʊ ðəɹ wɑz noʊ sɝpɹaɪz ɪn ɪz aɪz.

"The Light shine on us and protect us," Nynaeve whispered. Egwene clutched her as if she wanted to hide behind the Wisdom. Even Lan stirred uneasily, though there was no surprise in his eyes.

stoʊn θʌddɪɾ ɪndə ɹændz ʃoʊldɝz, ən i ɹilaɪzd i hæd bækt əz fɑɹ əz ðə wɔl, əz fɑɹ fɹəm ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld əz i kəd ɡɛt. hi wʊɾə pʊʃt hɪmsɛlf ɹaɪt θɹu ðə wɔl, ɪf i kəd hæv. mæt, tu, wɑz spleɪɾ aʊɾ əɡɛns ðə stoʊn əz flæɾ əz i kəd meɪk hɪmsɛlf. pɛɹɪn wɑz stɛɹɪŋ ət ðə pul wɪð ɪz æks hæf dʒɹɔn. hɪz aɪz ʃoʊn, jɛloʊ ən fɪɹs.

Stone thudded into Rand's shoulders, and he realized he had backed as far as the wall, as far from the Eye of the World as he could get. He would have pushed himself right through the wall, if he could have. Mat, too, was splayed out against the stone as flat as he could make himself. Perrin was staring at the pool with his axe half drawn. His eyes shone, yellow and fierce.

"aɪ ɔlweɪz wʌndɝd," lɔɪəl sɛɾ ənizəli. "wɛn aɪ ɹɛɾ əbaʊɾ ɪt, aɪ ɔlweɪz wʌndɝd wʌɾ ɪt wɑz. waɪ? waɪ dɪd ðeɪ də ɪt? ən haʊ?"

"I always wondered," Loial said uneasily. "When I read about it, I always wondered what it was. Why? Why did they do it? And how?"

"noʊ wʌn lɪvɪŋ noʊz." mɔɪɹeɪn noʊ lɔŋɡɝ lʊkt ət ðə pul. ʃi wɑz wɑtʃɪŋ ɹænd ən ɪz tu fɹɛnz, stʌɾiɪŋ ðɛm, hɝ aɪz weɪɪŋ. "niðɝ ðə haʊ, nɔɹ mɔɹ ə ðə waɪ ðən ðəɾ ɪt wəd bi niɾəd wʌn deɪ, ən ðət ðət nid wəd bi ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst ən moʊs dɛspɹɪt ðə wɝl hæd feɪs tə ðət taɪm. pɝhæps ɛvɝ wəd feɪs.

"No one living knows." Moiraine no longer looked at the pool. She was watching Rand and his two friends, studying them, her eyes weighing. "Neither the how, nor more of the why than that it would be needed one day, and that that need would be the greatest and most desperate the world had faced to that time. Perhaps ever would face.

"mɛni ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn əv ətɛmptəd tə faɪn ə weɪ tə juz ðɪs paʊɝ, bʌɾ ɪts əz əntʌtʃəbəl fəɹ ɛni wʊmən əz ðə mun ɪz fəɹ ə kæt. oʊnli ə mæn kəd tʃænəl ɪt, bʌt ðə læs meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz nɪɹli θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz ɡɔn. jɛt ðə nid ðeɪ sɔ wɑz ə dɛspɹɪt wʌn. ðeɪ wɝk θɹu ðə teɪn ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɑn seɪɾɪn tə meɪk ɪt, ən meɪk ɪt pjʊɹ, noʊɪŋ ðət duɪŋ soʊ wəd kɪl əm ɔl. meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ ən fimeɪl təɡɛðɝ. ðə ɡɹin mæn spoʊk tʃɹu. ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst wʌndɝz ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz wɝ dʌn ɪn ðət weɪ, seɪɾɪn ən seɪaɪdɑɹ təɡɛðɝ. ɔl ðə wɪmən ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn, ɔl ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪn ɔl ðə kɔɹts ən sɪɾiz, ivən wɪð ðoʊz ɪn ðə lænz bɪɑn ðə weɪst, ivən kaʊntɪŋ ðoʊz u meɪ stɪl laɪv bɪɑn ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, kəd nɑt fɪl ə spun wɪð ðə paʊɝ, lækɪŋ mɛn tə wɝk wɪð ðɛm."

"Many in Tar Valon have attempted to find a way to use this Power, but it is as untouchable for any woman as the moon is for a cat. Only a man could channel it, but the last male Aes Sedai is nearly three thousand years gone. Yet the need they saw was a desperate one. They worked through the taint of the Dark One on saidin to make it, and make it pure, knowing that doing so would kill them all. Male Aes Sedai and female together. The Green Man spoke true. The greatest wonders of the Age of Legends were done in that way, saidin and saidar together. All the women in Tar Valon, all the Aes Sedai in all the courts and cities, even with those in the lands beyond the Waste, even counting those who may still live beyond the Aryth Ocean, could not fill a spoon with the Power, lacking men to work with them."

ɹændz θɹoʊt ɹæspt əz ɪf i hæd bɪn skɹimɪŋ. "waɪ dɪd jə bɹɪŋ əs hɪɹ?"

Rand's throat rasped as if he had been screaming. "Why did you bring us here?"

"bɪkɔz jə ɑɹ tɑvɝən." ði ɛɛs sədaɪz feɪs wɑz ənɹiɾəbəl. hɝ aɪz ʃɪmɝd, ən sim tə pʊl ət hɪm. "bɪkɔz ðə dɑɹk wʌnz paʊɝ wɪl stʃɹaɪk hɪɹ, ən kəz ɪt mʌs bi kənfɹʌntəɾ ən stɑpt, əɹ ðə ʃædoʊ wɪl kʌvɝ ðə wɝld. ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid ɡɹeɪɾɝ ðən ðæt. lɛɾ əs ɡoʊ aʊɾ ɪndə ðə sʌnlaɪɾ əɡɛn, waɪl ðəɹ ɪz jɛt taɪm." wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ tə si ɪf ðeɪ wəd fɑloʊ, ʃi stɑɹɾəd bæk ʌp ðə kɔɹəɾɝ wɪð læn, hu stɛpt pɝhæps ə bɪt mɔɹ kwɪkli ðən juʒəwəl fəɹ hɪm. ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv hɝid bɪhaɪn hɝ.

"Because you are ta'veren." The Aes Sedai's face was unreadable. Her eyes shimmered, and seemed to pull at him. "Because the Dark One's power will strike here, and because it must be confronted and stopped, or the Shadow will cover the world. There is no need greater than that. Let us go out into the sunlight again, while there is yet time." Without waiting to see if they would follow, she started back up the corridor with Lan, who stepped perhaps a bit more quickly than usual for him. Egwene and Nynaeve hurried behind her.

ɹænd ɛdʒd əlɔŋ ðə wɔl - hi kəd nɑt meɪk hɪmsɛlf ɡɛɾ ivən wʌn stɛp kloʊsɝ tə wʌt ðə pul wɑz - ən skɹæmbəld ɪndə ðə kɔɹəɾɝ ɪn ə tæŋɡəl wɪð mæt ən pɛɹɪn. hi wʊɾə ɹʌn ɪf ɪt hæd nɑt mɛn tʃɹæmplɪŋ ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv, mɔɪɹeɪn ən læn. hi kəd nɑt stɑp ʃeɪkɪŋ ivən wən i wɑz bæk aʊtsaɪd.

Rand edged along the wall - he could not make himself get even one step closer to what the pool was - and scrambled into the corridor in a tangle with Mat and Perrin. He would have run if it had not meant trampling Egwene and Nynaeve, Moiraine and Lan. He could not stop shaking even when he was back outside.

"aɪ də nɑt laɪk ðɪs, mɔɪɹeɪn," nɪneɪiv sɛɾ æŋɡɹəli wən ðə sʌn ʃoʊn ɑn əm əɡɛn. "aɪ bɪliv ðə deɪnʒɝ ɪz əz ɡɹeɪɾ əz jə seɪ əɹ aɪ wəd nɑt bi hɪɹ, bʌt ðɪs ɪz - "

"I do not like this, Moiraine," Nynaeve said angrily when the sun shone on them again. "I believe the danger is as great as you say or I would not be here, but this is - "

"aɪ hæv faʊn jə ət læst."

"I have found you at last."

ɹænd dʒɝkt əz ɪf ə ɹoʊp hæd taɪɾənd ɝaʊn ɪz nɛk. ðə wɝdz, ðə vɔɪs . . . fəɹ ə moʊmən i bɪlivd ɪt wɑz bælzəmən. bʌt ðə tu mɛn u wɔkt aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz, feɪsəz hɪɾən baɪ ðɛɹ kaʊlz, dɪd nɑt wɛɹ kloʊks ðə kʌlɝ ə dʒɹaɪd blʌd. wʌn kloʊk wɑz ə dɑɹk ɡɹeɪ, ði ʌðɝ ɔlmoʊst əz dɑɹk ə ɡɹin, ən ðeɪ simd mʌsti ivən ɪn ði oʊpən ɛɹ. ən ðə mɛn wɝ nɑt feɪdz; ðə bɹiz stɝd ðɛɹ kloʊks.

Rand jerked as if a rope had tightened around his neck. The words, the voice . . . for a moment he believed it was Ba'alzamon. But the two men who walked out of the trees, faces hidden by their cowls, did not wear cloaks the color of dried blood. One cloak was a dark gray, the other almost as dark a green, and they seemed musty even in the open air. And the men were not Fades; the breeze stirred their cloaks.

"hu ɑɹ ju?" lænz stæns wɑz kɔʃəs, hɪz hæn ɑn ɪz sɔɹd hɪlt. "haʊ dɪd jə kʌm hɪɹ? ɪf jə ɑɹ sikɪŋ ðə ɡɹin mæn - "

"Who are you?" Lan's stance was cautious, his hand on his sword hilt. "How did you come here? If you are seeking the Green Man - "

"hi ɡaɪɾəd ʌs." ðə hæn ðət pɔɪntəd tə mæt wɑz oʊld ən ʃɹɪvəl tə skɛɹsli hjumən, lækɪŋ ə fɪŋɡɝneɪl ən wɪð nʌkəlz nɑɹld laɪk nɑts ɪn ə pis ə ɹoʊp. mæt tʊk ə stɛp bæk, aɪz waɪɾənɪŋ. "æn oʊl θɪŋ, ən oʊl fɹɛnd, ən oʊld ɛnəmi. bʌt hiz nɑt ðə wʌn wi sik," ðə ɡɹin-kloʊk mæn fɪnɪʃt. ði ʌðɝ mæn stʊɾ əz ɪf i wəd nɛvɝ spik.

"He guided us." The hand that pointed to Mat was old and shriveled to scarcely human, lacking a fingernail and with knuckles gnarled like knots in a piece of rope. Mat took a step back, eyes widening. "An old thing, an old friend, an old enemy. But he is not the one we seek," the green-cloaked man finished. The other man stood as if he would never speak.

mɔɪɹeɪn stʃɹeɪɾənd tə hɝ fʊl haɪt, noʊ mɔɹ ðən ʃoʊldɝ haɪ tə ɛni mæn ðɛɹ, bʌt sʌɾənli simɪŋ əz tɔl əz ðə hɪlz. hɝ vɔɪs ɹæŋ laɪk ə bɛl, dɪmændɪŋ, "hu ɑɹ ju?"

Moiraine straightened to her full height, no more than shoulder high to any man there, but suddenly seeming as tall as the hills. Her voice rang like a bell, demanding, "Who are you?"

hænz pʊʃt bæk hʊdz, ən ɹænd ɡɑɡəld. ði oʊl mæn wɑz oʊldɝ ðən oʊld; hi meɪd sɛn bui lʊk laɪk ə tʃaɪld ɪn ðə blum ə hɛlθ. ðə skɪn ə hɪz feɪs wɑz laɪk kɹeɪz pɑɹtʃmən dʒɹɔn taɪɾ oʊvɝ ə skʌl, ðən pʊl taɪɾɝ stɪl. wɪspi tʌfs ə bɹɪɾəl hɛɹ stʊɾ əɾ ɑd pleɪsəz ɑn ɪz skəbɹəs skælp. hɪz ɪɹz wɝ wɪðɝd bɪts laɪk skɹæps ʌv eɪntʃən lɛðɝ; hɪz aɪz sʌŋkən, piɹɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛɾ əz ɪf fɹəm ði ɛnz ə tʌnəlz. jɛt ði ʌðɝ wɑz wɝs. ə taɪt, blæk lɛðɝ kæɹəpɑtʃ kʌvɝd ðət wʌnz hɛɾ ən feɪs kəmplitli, bʌt ðə fɹʌn ʌv ɪt wɑz wɝkt ɪndə ə pɝfək feɪs, ə jʌŋ mænz feɪs, læfɪŋ waɪldli, læfɪŋ ənseɪnli, fɹoʊzən fɝɛvɝ. wʌɾ ɪz i haɪɾɪŋ ɪf ði ʌðɝ ʃoʊz wʌɾ i ʃoʊz? ðən ivən θɔt fɹoʊz ɪn ɪz hɛd, ʃæɾɝd tə dʌst ən blu əweɪ.

Hands pushed back hoods, and Rand goggled. The old man was older than old; he made Cenn Buie look like a child in the bloom of health. The skin of his face was like crazed parchment drawn tight over a skull, then pulled tighter still. Wispy tufts of brittle hair stood at odd places on his scabrous scalp. His ears were withered bits like scraps of ancient leather; his eyes sunken, peering out of his head as if from the ends of tunnels. Yet the other was worse. A tight, black leather carapace covered that one's head and face completely, but the front of it was worked into a perfect face, a young man's face, laughing wildly, laughing insanely, frozen forever. What is he hiding if the other shows what he shows? Then even thought froze in his head, shattered to dust and blew away.

"aɪ æm kɔld eɪdʒɪnɝ," ði oʊld wʌn sɛd. "æn hiz bælθəməl. hi noʊ lɔŋɡɝ spiks wɪð ɪz tʌŋ. ðə wil ɡɹaɪnz ɪksiɾɪŋli faɪn oʊvɝ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz ɪmpɹɪzənd." hɪz sʌŋkən aɪz slɪd tə ði ɑɹtʃ; bælθəməl lin fɔɹwɝd, hɪz mæsks aɪz ɑn ðə waɪt stoʊn oʊpənɪŋ, əz ɪf i wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ stʃɹeɪɾ ɪn. "soʊ lɔŋ wɪθaʊt," eɪdʒɪnɝ sɛd sɔfli. "soʊ lɔŋ."

"I am called Aginor," the old one said. "And he is Balthamel. He no longer speaks with his tongue. The Wheel grinds exceedingly fine over three thousand years imprisoned." His sunken eyes slid to the arch; Balthamel leaned forward, his mask's eyes on the white stone opening, as if he wanted to go straight in. "So long without," Aginor said softly. "So long."

"ðə laɪt pɹətɛkt - " lɔɪəl bɪɡæn, hɪz vɔɪs ʃeɪkɪŋ, ən kʌɾ ɔf əbɹʌpli wən eɪdʒɪnɝ lʊkt ət hɪm.

"The Light protect - " Loial began, his voice shaking, and cut off abruptly when Aginor looked at him.

"ðə fɔɹseɪkən," mæt sɛd hɔɹsli, "ɑɹ baʊn ɪn ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl - "

"The Forsaken," Mat said hoarsely, "are bound in Shayol Ghul - "

"wɝ baʊnd." eɪdʒɪnɝ smaɪld; hɪz jɛloʊd tiθ hæd ðə lʊk ə fæŋz. "sʌm ʌv əs ɑɹ baʊnd noʊ lɔŋɡɝ. ðə silz wikən, ɛɛs sədaɪ. laɪk ɪʃəml, wi wɔk ðə wɝld əɡɛn, ən sun ðə ɹɛst ʌv əs wɪl kʌm. aɪ wɑz tu kloʊz tə ðɪs wɝld ɪn maɪ kæptɪvəɾi, aɪ ən bælθəməl, tu kloʊs tə ðə ɡɹaɪndɪŋ ə ðə wil, bʌt sun ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wɪl bi fɹi, ən ɡɪv əs nu flɛʃ, ən ðə wɝld wɪl bi aʊɝz wʌns mɔɹ. jəl əv noʊ luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝ, ðɪs taɪm. noʊ lɔɹɾ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ tə seɪv ju. wi noʊ ðə wʌn wi sik naʊ, ən ðəɹ ɪz noʊ mɔɹ nid fəɹ ðə ɹɛst ə ju."

"Were bound." Aginor smiled; his yellowed teeth had the look of fangs. "Some of us are bound no longer. The seals weaken, Aes Sedai. Like Ishamael, we walk the world again, and soon the rest of us will come. I was too close to this world in my captivity, I and Balthamel, too close to the grinding of the Wheel, but soon the Great Lord of the Dark will be free, and give us new flesh, and the world will be ours once more. You will have no Lews Therin Kinslayer, this time. No Lord of the Morning to save you. We know the one we seek now, and there is no more need for the rest of you."

lænz sɔɹd spɹæŋ fɹəm ɪts skæbɝd tu fæs fəɹ ɹændz aɪ tə fɑloʊ. jɛt ðə wɔɹɾɝ hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, aɪz flɪkɝɪŋ tə mɔɪɹeɪn, tə nɪneɪiv. ðə tu wɪmən stʊd wɛl əpɑɹt; tə pʊt hɪmsɛlf bɪtwin iðɝ ə ðɛm ən ðə fɔɹseɪkən wəd pʊɾ ɪm fɝðɝ fɹəm ði ʌðɝ. oʊnli fəɹ ə hɑɹtbit ðə hɛzəteɪʃən læstəd, bʌɾ əz ðə wɔɹɾɝz fit muvd, eɪdʒɪnɝ ɹeɪzd ɪz hænd. ɪt wɑz ə skɔɹnfəl dʒɛstʃɝ, ə flɪpɪŋ ə hɪz nɑɹl fɪŋɡɝz əz ɪf tə ʃu əweɪ ə flaɪ. ðə wɔɹɾɝ flu bækwɝdz θɹu ði ɛɹ əz ðoʊ ə hjudʒ fɪs hæd kɑt hɪm. wɪð ə dʌl θʌd læn stʃɹʌk ðə stoʊn ɑɹtʃ, hæŋɪŋ ðəɹ fəɹ ən ɪnstən bɪfɔɹ dʒɹɑpɪŋ ɪn ə flæksɪd hip, hɪz sɔɹd laɪɪŋ nɪɹ ɪz aʊtstʃɹɛtʃt hænd.

Lan's sword sprang from its scabbard too fast for Rand's eye to follow. Yet the Warder hesitated, eyes flickering to Moiraine, to Nynaeve. The two women stood well apart; to put himself between either of them and the Forsaken would put him further from the other. Only for a heartbeat the hesitation lasted, but as the Warder's feet moved, Aginor raised his hand. It was a scornful gesture, a flipping of his gnarled fingers as if to shoo away a fly. The Warder flew backwards through the air as though a huge fist had caught him. With a dull thud Lan struck the stone arch, hanging there for an instant before dropping in a flaccid heap, his sword lying near his outstretched hand.

"noʊ!" nɪneɪiv skɹimd.

"NO!" Nynaeve screamed.

"bi stɪl!" mɔɪɹeɪn kəmændəd, bʌt bɪfɔɹ ɛniwʌn ɛls kəd muv ðə wɪzdəmz naɪf hæd lɛft əɹ bɛlt, ən ʃi wɑz ɹʌnɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə fɔɹseɪkən, hɝ smɔl bleɪɾ əpɹeɪzd.

"Be still!" Moiraine commanded, but before anyone else could move the Wisdom's knife had left her belt, and she was running toward the Forsaken, her small blade upraised.

"ðə laɪt blaɪn ju," ʃi kɹaɪd, stʃɹaɪkɪŋ əɾ eɪdʒɪnɝz tʃɛst.

"The Light blind you," she cried, striking at Aginor's chest.

ði ʌðɝ fɔɹseɪkən muv laɪk ə vaɪpɝ. waɪl əɹ bloʊ stɪl fɛl, bælθəməlz lɛðɝ-keɪs hæn dɑɹɾɪd aʊt tə siz əɹ tʃɪn, fɪŋɡɝz sɪŋkɪŋ ɪndə wʌn tʃik waɪl θʌm dʌɡ ɪndə ði ʌðɝ, dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ðə blʌɾ aʊt wɪð ðɛɹ pɹɛʃɝ ən ɹeɪzɪŋ ðə flɛʃ ɪn peɪl ɹɪdʒəz. ə kənvʌlʃən ɹæk nɪneɪiv fɹəm hɛd tə toʊ, əz ɪf ʃi hæd bɪn kɹæk laɪk ə wɪp. hɝ naɪf dʒɹɑp jusləsli fɹəm dæŋɡəlɪŋ fɪŋɡɝz əz bælθəməl lɪftəɾ əɹ baɪ hɪz ɡɹɪp, bɹɔɾ əɹ ʌp tə wɛɹ ðə lɛðɝ mæsk stɛɹɾ ɪndə hɝ stɪlkwɪvɝɪŋ feɪs. hɝ toʊz spæzmd ə fʊɾ əbʌv ðə ɡɹaʊnd; flaʊɝz ɹeɪn fɹəm əɹ hɛɹ.

The other Forsaken moved like a viper. While her blow still fell, Balthamel's leather-cased hand darted out to seize her chin, fingers sinking into one cheek while thumb dug into the other, driving the blood out with their pressure and raising the flesh in pale ridges. A convulsion wracked Nynaeve from head to toe, as if she had been cracked like a whip. Her knife dropped uselessly from dangling fingers as Balthamel lifted her by his grip, brought her up to where the leather mask stared into her stillquivering face. Her toes spasmed a foot above the ground; flowers rained from her hair.

"aɪ hæv ɔlmoʊs fɝɡɑɾən ðə plɛʒɝz ə ðə flɛʃ." eɪdʒɪnɝz tʌŋ kɹɔst ɪz wɪðɝd lɪps, saʊndɪŋ laɪk stoʊn ɑn ɹʌf lɛðɝ. "bʌt bælθəməl ɹɪmɛmbɝz mʌtʃ." ðə læftɝ ə ðə mæsk sim tə ɡɹoʊ waɪldɝ, ən ðə weɪl ðət lɛf nɪneɪiv bɝn ɹændz ɪɹz laɪk dɪspɛɹ ɹɪp fɹəm əɹ lɪvɪŋ hɑɹt.

"I have almost forgotten the pleasures of the flesh." Aginor's tongue crossed his withered lips, sounding like stone on rough leather. "But Balthamel remembers much." The laughter of the mask seemed to grow wilder, and the wail that left Nynaeve burned Rand's ears like despair ripped from her living heart.

sʌɾənli ɛɡwin muvd, ən ɹænd sɔ ðət ʃi wɑz gɑnə hɛlp nɪneɪiv. "ɛɡwin, noʊ!" hi ʃaʊɾəd, bʌt ʃi dɪd nɑt stɑp. hɪz hæn hæd ɡɔn tə hɪz sɔɹɾ ət nɪneɪivz kɹaɪ, bʌt naʊ hi əbændən ɪɾ ən θɹu hɪmsɛlf əɾ ɛɡwin. hi θʌddɪɾ ɪndə hɝ bɪfɔɹ ʃi tʊk əɹ θɝd stɛp, kæɹiɪŋ əm boʊθ tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. ɛɡwin lændəɾ ʌndɝ ɪm wɪð ə ɡæsp, ɪmiɾiətli θɹæʃɪŋ tə ɡɛt fɹi.

Suddenly Egwene moved, and Rand saw that she was going to help Nynaeve. "Egwene, no!" he shouted, but she did not stop. His hand had gone to his sword at Nynaeve's cry, but now he abandoned it and threw himself at Egwene. He thudded into her before she took her third step, carrying them both to the ground. Egwene landed under him with a gasp, immediately thrashing to get free.

ʌðɝz wɝ muvɪŋ, tu, hi ɹilaɪzd. pɛɹɪnz æks wɝld ɪndə hɪz hænz, ən ɪz aɪz ɡloʊd ɡoʊldən ən fɪɹs. "wɪzdəm!" mæt haʊld, ðə dæɡɝ fɹəm ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ ɪn ɪz fɪst.

Others were moving, too, he realized. Perrin's axe whirled into his hands, and his eyes glowed golden and fierce. "Wisdom!" Mat howled, the dagger from Shadar Logoth in his fist.

"noʊ!" ɹænd kɔld. "ju kæn faɪt ðə fɔɹseɪkən!" bʌt ðeɪ ɹæn pæst ɪm əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd nɑt hɝd, ðɛɹ aɪz ɑn nɪneɪiv ən ðə tu fɔɹseɪkən.

"No!" Rand called. "You can't fight the Forsaken!" But they ran past him as if they had not heard, their eyes on Nynaeve and the two Forsaken.

eɪdʒɪnɝ ɡlænst ət ðɛm, ʌnkənsɝnədli . . . ən smaɪld.

Aginor glanced at them, unconcernedly . . . and smiled.

ɹænd fɛl ði ɛɹ stɝ əbʌv ɪm laɪk ðə kɹæk ʌv ə dʒaɪəns wɪp. mæt ən pɛɹɪn, nɑɾ ivən hæfweɪ tə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, stɑpt əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd ɹʌn ɪndə ə wɔl, baʊns bæk tə spɹɔl ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

Rand felt the air stir above him like the crack of a giant's whip. Mat and Perrin, not even halfway to the Forsaken, stopped as if they had run into a wall, bounced back to sprawl on the ground.

"ɡʊd," eɪdʒɪnɝ sɛd. "ə fɪɾɪŋ pleɪs fəɹ ju. ɪf jə lɝn tə əbeɪs jɝsɛlf pɹɑpɝli ɪn wɝʃəp ʌv ʌs, aɪ maɪt lɛt jə lɪv."

"Good," Aginor said. "A fitting place for you. If you learn to abase yourself properly in worship of us, I might let you live."

heɪstəli ɹænd skɹæmbəl tə hɪz fit. pɝhæps i kəd nɑt faɪt ðə fɔɹseɪkən - noʊ ɔɹɾənɛɹi hjumən kəd - bʌɾ i wəd nɑt lɛɾ əm bɪliv fəɹ ə mɪnət ðəɾ i wɑz ɡɹɔvəlɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ðɛm. hi tʃɹaɪd tə hɛlp ɛɡwin ʌp, bʌt ʃi slæpt ɪz hænz əweɪ ən stʊd baɪ hɝsɛlf, æŋɡɹəli bɹʌʃɪŋ ɔf əɹ dʒɹɛs. mæt ən pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɔlsoʊ stʌbɝnli pʊʃt ðɛmsɛlvz ənstɛɾəli ɪɹɛkt.

Hastily Rand scrambled to his feet. Perhaps he could not fight the Forsaken - no ordinary human could - but he would not let them believe for a minute that he was groveling before them. He tried to help Egwene up, but she slapped his hands away and stood by herself, angrily brushing off her dress. Mat and Perrin had also stubbornly pushed themselves unsteadily erect.

"ju wɪl lɝn," eɪdʒɪnɝ sɛd, "ɪf jə wɑnə lɪv. naʊ ðəɾ aɪ hæv faʊnd wʌɾ aɪ nid" - hɪz aɪz wɛn tə ðə stoʊn ɑɹtʃweɪ - "aɪ meɪ teɪk ðə taɪm tə titʃ ju."

"You will learn," Aginor said, "if you want to live. Now that I have found what I need" - his eyes went to the stone archway - "I may take the time to teach you."

"ðɪs ʃæl nɑt bi!" ðə ɡɹin mæn stʃɹoʊɾ aʊɾ ə ðə tʃɹiz wɪð ə vɔɪs laɪk laɪtnɪŋ stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ən eɪntʃən oʊk. "ju də nɑt bɪlɔŋ hɪɹ!"

"This shall not be!" The Green Man strode out of the trees with a voice like lightning striking an ancient oak. "You do not belong here!"

eɪdʒɪnɝ spɛɹɾ ɪm ə bɹif, kəntɛmptʃuəs ɡlæns. "bɪɡɔn! jəɹ taɪm ɪz ɛndəd, ɔl jəɹ kaɪn bʌt jə lɔŋ sɪns dʌst. lɪv wʌt laɪf ɪz lɛf tə jə ən bi ɡlæd jə ɑɹ bɪniθ əɹ noʊɾəs."

Aginor spared him a brief, contemptuous glance. "Begone! Your time is ended, all your kind but you long since dust. Live what life is left to you and be glad you are beneath our notice."

"ðɪs ɪz maɪ pleɪs," ðə ɡɹin mæn sɛd, "æn jə ʃæl hɝt noʊ lɪvɪŋ θɪŋ hɪɹ."

"This is my place," the Green Man said, "and you shall hurt no living thing here."

bælθəməl tɔs nɪneɪiv əsaɪd laɪk ə ɹæɡ, ən laɪk ə kɹʌmpəld ɹæɡ ʃi fɛl, aɪz stɛɹɪŋ, lɪmp əz ɪf ɔl əɹ boʊnz hæd mɛltəd. wʌn lɛðɝ-klæd hæn lɪftəd, ən ðə ɡɹin mæn ɹɔɹɾ əz smoʊk ɹoʊz fɹəm ðə vaɪnz ðət woʊv hɪm. ðə wɪn ɪn ðə tʃɹiz ɛkoʊɾ ɪz peɪn.

Balthamel tossed Nynaeve aside like a rag, and like a crumpled rag she fell, eyes staring, limp as if all her bones had melted. One leather-clad hand lifted, and the Green Man roared as smoke rose from the vines that wove him. The wind in the trees echoed his pain.

eɪdʒɪnɝ tɝn bæk tə ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz, əz ɪf ðə ɡɹin mæn hæd bɪn dɛlt wɪð, bʌt wʌn lɔŋ stʃɹaɪɾ ən mæsɪv, lifi ɑɹmz ɹæp ðɛmsɛlvz ɝaʊn bælθəməl, ɹeɪzɪŋ ɪm haɪ, kɹʌʃɪŋ ɪm əɡɛnst ə tʃɛst ə θɪk kɹipɝz, blæk lɛðɝ mæsk læfɪŋ ɪndə heɪzəlnʌɾ aɪz dɑɹk wɪð æŋɡɝ. laɪk sɝpəns bælθəməlz ɑɹmz ɹɪθ fɹi, hɪz ɡlʌv hænz ɡɹæspɪŋ ðə ɡɹin mænz hɛɾ əz ðoʊ hi wəd ɹɛntʃ ɪɾ ɔf. fleɪmz ʃɑɾ ʌp wɛɹ ðoʊz hænz tʌtʃt, vaɪnz wɪðɝɪŋ, livz fɔlɪŋ. ðə ɡɹin mæn bɛloʊɾ əz θɪk, dɑɹk smoʊk pɔɹɾ aʊt bɪtwin ðə vaɪnz ə hɪz bɑɾi. ɑn ən ɑn i ɹɔɹd, əz ɪf ɔl ə hɪm wɝ kʌmɪŋ aʊɾ ə hɪz maʊθ wɪð ðə smoʊk ðət bɪloʊd bɪtwin ɪz lɪps.

Aginor turned back to Rand and the others, as if the Green Man had been dealt with, but one long stride and massive, leafy arms wrapped themselves around Balthamel, raising him high, crushing him against a chest of thick creepers, black leather mask laughing into hazelnut eyes dark with anger. Like serpents Balthamel's arms writhed free, his gloved hands grasping the Green Man's head as though he would wrench it off. Flames shot up where those hands touched, vines withering, leaves falling. The Green Man bellowed as thick, dark smoke poured out between the vines of his body. On and on he roared, as if all of him were coming out of his mouth with the smoke that billowed between his lips.

sʌɾənli bælθəməl dʒɝkt ɪn ðə ɡɹin mænz ɡɹæsp. ðə fɔɹseɪkənz hænz tʃɹaɪd tə pʊʃ ɪm əweɪ ɪnstɛɾ ə klʌtʃɪŋ hɪm. wʌn ɡlʌv hæn flʌŋ waɪd . . . ən ə taɪni kɹipɝ bɝs θɹu ðə blæk lɛðɝ. ə fʌŋɡəs, sətʃ əz ɹɪŋz tʃɹiz ɪn ðə dip ʃædoʊz ə ðə fɔɹəst, ɹɪŋd ɪz ɑɹm, spɹæŋ fɹəm noʊwɛɹ tə fʊl-ɡɹoʊn, swɛlɪŋ tə kʌvɝ ðə lɛŋθ ʌv ɪt. bælθəməl θɹæʃt, ən ə ʃuɾ ə stɪŋkwid ɹɪpt oʊpən ɪz kæɹəpɑtʃ, laɪkənz dʌɡ ɪn ðɛɹ ɹuts ən splɪt taɪni kɹæks əkɹɔs ðə lɛðɝ ə hɪz feɪs, nɛɾəlz bɹoʊk ði aɪz ə hɪz mæsk, dɛθshɛd mʌʃɹumz tɔɹ oʊpən ðə maʊθ.

Suddenly Balthamel jerked in the Green Man's grasp. The Forsaken's hands tried to push him away instead of clutching him. One gloved hand flung wide . . . and a tiny creeper burst through the black leather. A fungus, such as rings trees in the deep shadows of the forest, ringed his arm, sprang from nowhere to full-grown, swelling to cover the length of it. Balthamel thrashed, and a shoot of stinkweed ripped open his carapace, lichens dug in their roots and split tiny cracks across the leather of his face, nettles broke the eyes of his mask, deathshead mushrooms tore open the mouth.

ðə ɡɹin mæn θɹu ðə fɔɹseɪkən daʊn. bælθəməl twɪstəɾ ən dʒɝkt əz ɔl ðə θɪŋz ðət ɡɹu ɪn ðə dɑɹk pleɪsəz, ɔl ðə θɪŋz wɪð spɔɹz, ɔl ðə θɪŋz ðət lʌv ðə dæŋk, swɛld ən ɡɹu, tɔɹ klɔθ ən lɛðɝ ən flɛʃ - wɑz ɪt flɛʃ, sin ɪn ðət bɹif moʊmən ə vɝɾənt ɹeɪdʒ? - tə tæɾɝd ʃɹɛdz ən kʌvɝɾ ɪm əntɪl oʊnli ə maʊn ɹɪmeɪnd, ɪndɪstɪŋɡwɪʃəbəl fɹəm mɛni ɪn ðə ʃeɪɾɪd dɛpθs ə ðə ɡɹin fɔɹəst, ən ðə maʊn muv noʊ mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ.

The Green Man threw the Forsaken down. Balthamel twisted and jerked as all the things that grew in the dark places, all the things with spores, all the things that loved the dank, swelled and grew, tore cloth and leather and flesh - Was it flesh, seen in that brief moment of verdant rage? - to tattered shreds and covered him until only a mound remained, indistinguishable from many in the shaded depths of the green forest, and the mound moved no more than they.

wɪð ə ɡɹoʊn laɪk ə lɪm bɹeɪkɪŋ ʌndɝ tu ɡɹeɪɾ ə weɪt, ðə ɡɹin mæn kɹæʃt tə ðə ɡɹaʊnd. hæf ɪz hɛd wɑz tʃɑɹd blæk. tɛnʒɹəlz ə smoʊk stɪl ɹoʊz fɹəm hɪm, laɪk ɡɹeɪ kɹipɝz. bɝn livz fɛl fɹəm ɪz ɑɹm əz i peɪnfəli stʃɹɛtʃt aʊɾ ɪz blækən hæn tə dʒɛnli kʌp ən eɪkɔɹn.

With a groan like a limb breaking under too great a weight, the Green Man crashed to the ground. Half his head was charred black. Tendrils of smoke still rose from him, like gray creepers. Burned leaves fell from his arm as he painfully stretched out his blackened hand to gently cup an acorn.

ði ɝθ ɹʌmbəld əz ən oʊk sidlɪŋ pʊʃt ʌp bɪtwin ɪz fɪŋɡɝz. ðə ɡɹin mænz hɛd fɛl, bʌt ðə sidlɪŋ ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə sʌn, stʃɹeɪnɪŋ. ɹuts ʃɑɾ aʊɾ ən θɪkənd, dɛlv bɪniθ ðə ɡɹaʊn ən ɹoʊz əɡɛn, θɪkən mɔɹ əz ðeɪ sæŋk. ðə tʃɹʌŋk bɹɔɾənd ən stʃɹɛtʃt ʌpwɝd, bɑɹk tɝnɪŋ ɡɹeɪ ən fɪʃɝɾ ən eɪntʃənt. lɪmz spɹɛɾ ən ɡɹu hɛvi, əz bɪɡ əz ɑɹmz, əz bɪɡ əz mɛn, ən lɪftəd tə kɝɛs ðə skaɪ, θɪk wɪð ɡɹin livz, dɛns wɪð eɪkɔɹnz. ðə mæsɪv wɛb ə ɹuts tɝn ði ɝθ laɪk plaʊz əz ɪt spɹɛd; ði ɔlɹɛɾi hjudʒ tʃɹʌŋk ʃɪvɝd, ɡɹu waɪɾɝ, ɹaʊn əz ə haʊs. stɪlnəs keɪm. ən ən oʊk ðət cʊɾə stʊd faɪv hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz kʌvɝd ðə spɑt wɛɹ ðə ɡɹin mæn hæd bɪn, mɑɹkɪŋ ðə tum ʌv ə lɛdʒənd. nɪneɪiv leɪ ɑn ðə nɑɹld ɹuts, ɡɹoʊn kɝv tə hɝ ʃeɪp, tə meɪk ə bɛd fəɹ əɹ tə ɹɛst əpɑn. ðə wɪn saɪd θɹu ði oʊks bɹæntʃəz; ɪt sim tə mɝmɝ fɛɹwɛl.

The earth rumbled as an oak seedling pushed up between his fingers. The Green Man's head fell, but the seedling reached for the sun, straining. Roots shot out and thickened, delved beneath the ground and rose again, thickened more as they sank. The trunk broadened and stretched upward, bark turning gray and fissured and ancient. Limbs spread and grew heavy, as big as arms, as big as men, and lifted to caress the sky, thick with green leaves, dense with acorns. The massive web of roots turned the earth like plows as it spread; the already huge trunk shivered, grew wider, round as a house. Stillness came.
