And an oak that could have stood five hundred years covered the spot where the Green Man had been, marking the tomb of a legend. Nynaeve lay on the gnarled roots, grown curved to her shape, to make a bed for her to rest upon. The wind sighed through the oak's branches; it seemed to murmur farewell.

ivən eɪdʒɪnɝ sim stʌnd. ðən ɪz hɛd lɪftəd, kævɝnəs aɪz bɝnɪŋ wɪð heɪt. "ɪnʌf! ɪts pæs taɪm tə ɛn ðɪs!"

Even Aginor seemed stunned. Then his head lifted, cavernous eyes burning with hate. "Enough! It is past time to end this!"

"jɛs, fɔɹseɪkən," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd, hɝ vɔɪs əz koʊld əz dipwɪntɝ aɪs. "pæs taɪm!"

"Yes, Forsaken," Moiraine said, her voice as cold as deepwinter ice. "Past time!"

ði ɛɛs sədaɪz hæn ɹoʊz, ən ðə ɡɹaʊn fɛl əweɪ bɪniθ eɪdʒɪnɝz fit. fleɪm ɹɔɹd fɹəm ðə kæzəm, wɪp tə ə fɹɛnzi baɪ wɪn haʊlɪŋ ɪn fɹəm ɛvɹi dɝɛkʃən, sʌkɪŋ ə meɪlstʃɹəm ə livz ɪndə ðə faɪɝ, wɪtʃ sim tə səlɪɾəfaɪ ɪndə ə ɹɛd-stʃɹik jɛloʊ dʒɛli ʌv pjʊɹ hit. ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ɪɾ eɪdʒɪnɝ stʊd, hɪz fit səpɔɹɾəd oʊnli baɪ ɛɹ. ðə fɔɹseɪkən lʊk stɑɹɾəld, bʌt ðən i smaɪld ən tʊk ə stɛp fɔɹwɝd. ɪt wɑz ə sloʊ stɛp, əz ɪf ðə faɪɝ tʃɹaɪd tə ɹuɾ ɪm tə ðə spɑt, bʌɾ i tʊk ɪt, ən ðən ənʌðɝ.

The Aes Sedai's hand rose, and the ground fell away beneath Aginor's feet. Flame roared from the chasm, whipped to a frenzy by wind howling in from every direction, sucking a maelstrom of leaves into the fire, which seemed to solidify into a red-streaked yellow jelly of pure heat. In the middle of it Aginor stood, his feet supported only by air. The Forsaken looked startled, but then he smiled and took a step forward. It was a slow step, as if the fire tried to root him to the spot, but he took it, and then another.

"ɹʌn!" mɔɪɹeɪn kəmændəd. hɝ feɪs wɑz waɪt wɪð stʃɹeɪn. "ɔl ə jə ɹʌn!" eɪdʒɪnɝ stɛpt əkɹɔs ði ɛɹ, təwɔɹd ði ɛdʒ ə ðə fleɪmz.

"Run!" Moiraine commanded. Her face was white with strain. "All of you run!" Aginor stepped across the air, toward the edge of the flames.

ɹænd wɑz əwɛɹ ʌv ʌðɝz muvɪŋ, mæt ən pɛɹɪn dæʃɪŋ əweɪ ət ði ɛdʒ ə hɪz vɪʒən, lɔɪəlz lɔŋ lɛɡz kæɹiɪŋ ɪm ɪndə ðə tʃɹiz, bʌɾ ɔl i kəd ɹɪli si wɑz ɛɡwin. ʃi stʊd ðəɹ ɹɪdʒəd, feɪs peɪl ən aɪz kloʊzd. ɪt wɑz nɑt fɪɹ ðət hɛl hɝ, hi ɹilaɪzd. ʃi wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə θɹoʊ hɝ pjuni, əntʃɹeɪnd wildɪŋ ə ðə paʊɝ əɡɛns ðə fɔɹseɪkən.

Rand was aware of others moving, Mat and Perrin dashing away at the edge of his vision, Loial's long legs carrying him into the trees, but all he could really see was Egwene. She stood there rigid, face pale and eyes closed. It was not fear that held her, he realized. She was trying to throw her puny, untrained wielding of the Power against the Forsaken.

ɹʌfli hi ɡɹæbd əɹ ɑɹm ən pʊld əɹ ɝaʊn tə feɪs hɪm. "ɹʌn!" hi ʃaʊɾəd ət hɝ. hɝ aɪz oʊpənd, stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm, æŋɡɹi wɪð ɪm fəɹ ɪntɝfɪɹɪŋ, lɪkwəd wɪð heɪt fəɹ eɪdʒɪnɝ, wɪð fɪɹ ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən. "ɹʌn," hi sɛd, pʊʃɪŋ əɹ təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹiz hɑɹɾ ɪnʌf tə stɑɹt hɝ. "ɹʌn!" wʌns stɑɹɾəd, ʃi dɪd ɹʌn.

Roughly he grabbed her arm and pulled her around to face him. "Run!" he shouted at her. Her eyes opened, staring at him, angry with him for interfering, liquid with hate for Aginor, with fear of the Forsaken. "Run," he said, pushing her toward the trees hard enough to start her. "Run!" Once started, she did run.

bʌɾ eɪdʒɪnɝz wɪðɝd feɪs tɝn təwɔɹd hɪm, təwɔɹd ðə ɹʌnɪŋ ɛɡwin bɪhaɪn hɪm, əz ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɔk θɹu ðə fleɪmz, əz ɪf wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz duɪŋ dɪd nɑt kənsɝn eɪdʒɪnɝ əɾ ɔl. təwɔɹɾ ɛɡwin.

But Aginor's withered face turned toward him, toward the running Egwene behind him, as the Forsaken walked through the flames, as if what the Aes Sedai was doing did not concern Aginor at all. Toward Egwene.

"nɑt hɝ!" ɹænd ʃaʊɾəd. "ðə laɪt bɝn ju, nɑt hɝ!" hi snætʃt ʌp ə ɹɑk ən θɹu ɪt, minɪŋ tə dʒɹɔ eɪdʒɪnɝz ətɛnʃən. hæfweɪ tə ðə fɔɹseɪkənz feɪs, ðə stoʊn tɝn tə ə hændfʊl ə dʌst.

"Not her!" Rand shouted. "The Light burn you, not her!" He snatched up a rock and threw it, meaning to draw Aginor's attention. Halfway to the Forsaken's face, the stone turned to a handful of dust.

hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd oʊnli ə moʊmənt, lɔŋ ɪnʌf tə ɡlæns oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ ən si ðəɾ ɛɡwin wɑz hɪɾən ɪn ðə tʃɹiz. ðə fleɪmz stɪl sɝaʊndəɾ eɪdʒɪnɝ, pætʃəz ə hɪz kloʊk smoʊldɝɪŋ, bʌɾ i wɔkt əz ɪf i hæɾ ɔl ðə taɪm ɪn ðə wɝld, ən ðə faɪɝz ɹɪm wɑz nɪɹ. ɹænd tɝn ən ɹæn. bɪhaɪn ɪm i hɝd mɔɪɹeɪn bɪɡɪn tə skɹim.

He hesitated only a moment, long enough to glance over his shoulder and see that Egwene was hidden in the trees. The flames still surrounded Aginor, patches of his cloak smoldering, but he walked as if he had all the time in the world, and the fire's rim was near. Rand turned and ran. Behind him he heard Moiraine begin to scream.


tʃæptɝ fɪftiwʌn


CHAPTER 51

əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ


Against the Shadow

ðə læn tɛndəɾ ʌpwɝd ðə weɪ ɹænd wɛnt, bʌt fɪɹ lɛn ɪz lɛɡz stʃɹɛŋkθ ən ðeɪ eɪt ɡɹaʊn ɪn lɔŋ stʃɹaɪdz, tɛɹɪŋ ɪz weɪ θɹu flaʊɝɪŋ bʊʃəz ən tæŋɡəlz ʌv waɪldʒɹoʊz, skæɾɝɪŋ pɛɾəlz, nɑt kɛɹɪŋ ɪf θɔɹnz ɹɪpt ɪz kloʊðz əɹ ivən ɪz flɛʃ. mɔɪɹeɪn hæd stɑp skɹimɪŋ. ɪt simd əz ɪf ðə ʃɹiks hæd ɡɔn ɑn fɝɛvɝ, itʃ wʌn mɔɹ θɹoʊt-ɹɛntʃɪŋ ðən ðə læst, bʌɾ i nu ðeɪ hæd læstəɾ oʊnli moʊməns ɔltəɡɛðɝ. moʊməns bɪfɔɹ eɪdʒɪnɝ wəd bi ɑn ɪz tʃɹeɪl. hi nu ɪt wəd bi hɪm ðəɾ eɪdʒɪnɝ fɑloʊd. hi hæd sin ðə sɝɾənti ɪn ðə fɔɹseɪkənz hɑloʊ aɪz, ɪn ðət læst sɛkən bɪfɔɹ tɛɹɝ wɪpt ɪz fit tə ɹʌn.

The land tended upward the way Rand went, but fear lent his legs strength and they ate ground in long strides, tearing his way through flowering bushes and tangles of wildrose, scattering petals, not caring if thorns ripped his clothes or even his flesh. Moiraine had stopped screaming. It seemed as if the shrieks had gone on forever, each one more throat-wrenching than the last, but he knew they had lasted only moments altogether. Moments before Aginor would be on his trail. He knew it would be him that Aginor followed. He had seen the certainty in the Forsaken's hollow eyes, in that last second before terror whipped his feet to run.

ðə lænd ɡɹu ɛvɝ stipɝ, bʌɾ i skɹæmbəld ɑn, pʊlɪŋ hɪmsɛlf fɔɹwɝd baɪ hænfəlz ʌv ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ, ɹɑks ən dɝɾ ən livz spɪlɪŋ daʊn ðə sloʊp fɹəm ʌndɝ ɪz fit, faɪnəli kɹɔlɪŋ ɑn hænz ən niz wən ðə slæn bɪkeɪm tu ɡɹeɪt. əhɛd, əbʌv, ɪt lɛvəld aʊɾ ə lɪɾəl. pæntɪŋ, hi skɹæbəld ɪz weɪ ðə læs fju spænz, ɡɑt tə hɪz fit, ən stɑpt, wɑntɪŋ tə haʊl əlaʊd.

The land grew ever steeper, but he scrambled on, pulling himself forward by handfuls of undergrowth, rocks and dirt and leaves spilling down the slope from under his feet, finally crawling on hands and knees when the slant became too great. Ahead, above, it leveled out a little. Panting, he scrabbled his way the last few spans, got to his feet, and stopped, wanting to howl aloud.

tɛn peɪsɪz ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪm, ðə hɪltɑp dʒɹɑpt əweɪ ʃɑɹpli. hi nu wʌɾ i wəd si bɪfɔɹ i ɹitʃt ɪt, bʌɾ i tʊk ðə stɛps ɛniweɪ, itʃ hɛviɝ ðən ðə wʌn bɪfɔɹ, hoʊpɪŋ ðəɹ maɪt bi səm tʃɹæk, ə ɡoʊt pæθ, ɛniθɪŋ. ət ði ɛdʒ i lʊk daʊn ə ʃɪɹ hʌnʒɹəd-fʊt dʒɹɑp, ə stoʊn wɔl əz smuð əz pleɪn tɪmbɝ.

Ten paces in front of him, the hilltop dropped away sharply. He knew what he would see before he reached it, but he took the steps anyway, each heavier than the one before, hoping there might be some track, a goat path, anything. At the edge he looked down a sheer hundred-foot drop, a stone wall as smooth as planed timber.

ðəɹ əz tə bi səm weɪ. əl ɡoʊ bæk ən faɪn ə weɪ ɝaʊnd. ɡoʊ bæk ən -  wən i tɝnd, eɪdʒɪnɝ wɑz ðɛɹ, dʒʌst ɹitʃɪŋ ðə kɹɛst. ðə fɔɹseɪkən tɑp ðə hɪl wɪθaʊɾ ɛni dɪfəkəlti, wɔkɪŋ ʌp ðə stip sloʊp əz ɪf ɪt wɝ lɛvəl ɡɹaʊnd. dip-sʌŋkən aɪz bɝn əɾ ɪm fɹəm ðət dʒɹɔn pɑɹtʃmən feɪs; sʌmhaʊ, ɪt sim lɛs wɪðɝd ðən bɪfɔɹ, mɔɹ flɛʃt, əz ɪf eɪdʒɪnɝ hæd fɛd wɛl ɑn sʌmθɪŋ. ðoʊz aɪz wɝ fɪkst ɑn hɪm, jɛt wən eɪdʒɪnɝ spoʊk, ɪt wɑz ɔlmoʊs tə hɪmsɛlf.

There has to be some way. I'll go back and find a way around. Go back and -  When he turned, Aginor was there, just reaching the crest. The Forsaken topped the hill without any difficulty, walking up the steep slope as if it were level ground. Deep-sunken eyes burned at him from that drawn parchment face; somehow, it seemed less withered than before, more fleshed, as if Aginor had fed well on something. Those eyes were fixed on him, yet when Aginor spoke, it was almost to himself.

"bælzəmən wɪl ɡɪv ɹɪwɔɹdz bɪɑn mɔɹɾəl dʒɹimɪŋ fəɹ ðə wʌn u bɹɪŋz jə tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. jɛt maɪ dʒɹimz əv ɔlweɪz bɪn bɪɑn ðoʊz ʌv ʌðɝ mɛn, ən aɪ lɛf mɔɹtæləɾi bɪhaɪn məlɛniə əɡoʊ. wʌt dɪfɝəns ɪf jə sɝv ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk əlaɪv əɹ dɛd? nʌn, tə ðə spɹɛɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. waɪ ʃəɾ aɪ ʃɛɹ paʊɝ wɪð ju? waɪ ʃəɾ aɪ bɛnd ni tə ju? aɪ, hu feɪs luz θɝɪn tɛləmən ɪn ðə hɔl ə ðə sɝvəns ɪtsɛlf. aɪ, hu θɹu maɪ maɪɾ əɡɛns ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ ən mɛɾ ɪm stʃɹoʊk fəɹ stʃɹoʊk. aɪ θɪŋk nɑt."

"Ba'alzamon will give rewards beyond mortal dreaming for the one who brings you to Shayol Ghul. Yet my dreams have always been beyond those of other men, and I left mortality behind millennia ago. What difference if you serve the Great Lord of the Dark alive or dead? None, to the spread of the Shadow. Why should I share power with you? Why should I bend knee to you? I, who faced Lews Therin Telamon in the Hall of the Servants itself. I, who threw my might against the Lord of the Morning and met him stroke for stroke. I think not."

ɹændz maʊθ dʒɹaɪd laɪk dʌst; hɪz tʌŋ fɛlt əz ʃɹɪvəld əz eɪdʒɪnɝ. ði ɛdʒ ə ðə pɹɛsəpəs ɡɹeɪɾɪd ʌndɝ ɪz hilz, stoʊn fɔlɪŋ əweɪ. hi dɪd nɑt dɛɹ lʊk bæk, bʌɾ i hɝd ðə ɹɑks baʊndɪŋ ən ɹɪbaʊndɪŋ fɹəm ðə ʃɪɹ wɔl, dʒʌst əz ɪz bɑɾi wəɾ ɪf i muvd ənʌðɝ ɪntʃ. ɪt wɑz ðə fɝst i nu ðəɾ i hæd bɪn bækɪŋ ʌp, əweɪ fɹəm ðə fɔɹseɪkən. hɪz skɪn kɹɔld əntɪl i θɔɾ i mʌst si ɪt ɹaɪðɪŋ ɪf i lʊkt, ɪf i kəɾ oʊnli teɪk ɪz aɪz ɔf ðə fɔɹseɪkən. ðəɹ əz tə bi səm weɪ tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm hɪm. səm weɪ tə ɪskeɪp! ðəɹ əz tə bi! səm weɪ!

Rand's mouth dried like dust; his tongue felt as shriveled as Aginor. The edge of the precipice grated under his heels, stone falling away. He did not dare look back, but he heard the rocks bounding and rebounding from the sheer wall, just as his body would if he moved another inch. It was the first he knew that he had been backing up, away from the Forsaken. His skin crawled until he thought he must see it writhing if he looked, if he could only take his eyes off the Forsaken. There has to be some way to get away from him. Some way to escape! There has to be! Some way!

sʌɾənli hi fɛl sʌmθɪŋ, sɔ ɪt, ðoʊ hi nu ɪt wɑz nɑt ðəɹ tə si. ə ɡloʊɪŋ ɹoʊp ɹæn ɔf fɹəm eɪdʒɪnɝ, bɪhaɪn hɪm, waɪt laɪk sʌnlaɪt sin θɹu ðə pjʊɹəs klaʊd, hɛviɝ ðən ə blæksmɪθs ɑɹm, laɪɾɝ ðən ɛɹ, kənɛktɪŋ ðə fɔɹseɪkən tə sʌmθɪŋ dɪstən bɪɑnd noʊɪŋ, sʌmθɪŋ wɪðɪn ðə tʌtʃ ə ɹændz hænd. ðə ɹoʊp pʌlsd, ən wɪð ɛvɹi θɹəb eɪdʒɪnɝ ɡɹu stʃɹɔŋɝ, mɔɹ fʊli flɛʃt, ə mæn əz tɔl ən stʃɹɔŋ əz hɪmsɛlf, ə mæn hɑɹɾɝ ðən ðə wɔɹɾɝ, mɔɹ dɛdli ðən ðə blaɪt. jɛt bɪsaɪd ðət ʃaɪnɪŋ kɔɹd, ðə fɔɹseɪkən simd ɔlmoʊs nɑt tə ɪɡzɪst. ðə kɔɹd wɑz ɔl. ɪt hʌmd. ɪt sæŋ. ɪt kɔld ɹændz soʊl. wʌn bɹaɪt fɪŋɡɝ-stʃɹæn lɪftəɾ əweɪ, dʒɹɪftəd, tʌtʃt hɪm, ən i ɡæspt. laɪt fɪl hɪm, ən hit ðət ʃʊɾə bɝn jɛɾ oʊnli wɔɹmd əz ɪf ɪt tʊk ðə tʃɪl ə ðə ɡɹeɪv fɹəm ɪz boʊnz. ðə stʃɹæn θɪkənd. aɪ hæv tə ɡɛɾ əweɪ!

Suddenly he felt something, saw it, though he knew it was not there to see. A glowing rope ran off from Aginor, behind him, white like sunlight seen through the purest cloud, heavier than a blacksmith's arm, lighter than air, connecting the Forsaken to something distant beyond knowing, something within the touch of Rand's hand. The rope pulsed, and with every throb Aginor grew stronger, more fully fleshed, a man as tall and strong as himself, a man harder than the Warder, more deadly than the Blight. Yet beside that shining cord, the Forsaken seemed almost not to exist. The cord was all. It hummed. It sang. It called Rand's soul. One bright finger-strand lifted away, drifted, touched him, and he gasped. Light filled him, and heat that should have burned yet only warmed as if it took the chill of the grave from his bones. The strand thickened. I have to get away!

"noʊ!" eɪdʒɪnɝ ʃaʊɾəd. "ju ʃæl nɑɾ əv ɪt! ɪts maɪn!"

"No!" Aginor shouted. "You shall not have it! It is mine!"

ɹænd dɪd nɑt muv, ən niðɝ dɪd ðə fɔɹseɪkən, jɛt ðeɪ fɔɾ əz ʃʊɹli əz ɪf ðeɪ ɡɹæpəld ɪn ðə dʌst. swɛt biɾɪd ɑn eɪdʒɪnɝz feɪs, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ wɪðɝd, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ oʊld, ðəɾ ʌv ə stʃɹɔŋ mæn ɪn ɪz pɹaɪm. ɹænd pʌlsd wɪð ðə biɾɪŋ ɪn ðə kɔɹd, laɪk ðə hɑɹtbiɾ ə ðə wɝld. ɪt fɪld ɪz biɪŋ. laɪt fɪld ɪz maɪnd, tɪl oʊnli ə kɔɹnɝ wɑz lɛft fəɹ wʌt wɑz hɪmsɛlf. hi ɹæp ðə vɔɪɾ ɝaʊn ðət nʊk; ʃɛltɝɾ ɪn ɛmptinəs. əweɪ!

Rand did not move, and neither did the Forsaken, yet they fought as surely as if they grappled in the dust. Sweat beaded on Aginor's face, no longer withered, no longer old, that of a strong man in his prime. Rand pulsed with the beating in the cord, like the heartbeat of the world. It filled his being. Light filled his mind, till only a corner was left for what was himself. He wrapped the void around that nook; sheltered in emptiness. Away!

"maɪn!" eɪdʒɪnɝ kɹaɪd. "maɪn!"

"Mine!" Aginor cried. "Mine!"

wɔɹmθ bɪlt ɪn ɹænd, ðə wɔɹmθ ə ðə sʌn, ðə ɹeɪdʒjəns ə ðə sʌn, bɝstɪŋ, ði ɑfəl ɹeɪdʒjəns ə laɪt, ʌv ðə laɪt. əweɪ!

Warmth built in Rand, the warmth of the sun, the radiance of the sun, bursting, the awful radiance of light, of the Light. Away!

"maɪn!" fleɪm ʃɑt fɹəm eɪdʒɪnɝz maʊθ, bɹoʊk θɹu hɪz aɪz laɪk spɪɹz ə faɪɝ, ən i skɹimd.

"Mine!" Flame shot from Aginor's mouth, broke through his eyes like spears of fire, and he screamed.

əweɪ!

Away!

ən ɹænd wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ɑn ðə hɪltɑp. hi kwɪvɝd wɪð ðə laɪt ðət səfjuz hɪm. hɪz maɪnd wəd nɑt wɝk; laɪɾ ən hit blaɪndɪɾ ɪt. ðə laɪt. ɪn ðə mɪdst ə ðə vɔɪd, ðə laɪt blaɪndɪɾ ɪz maɪnd, stʌn ɪm wɪð ɑ.

And Rand was no longer on the hilltop. He quivered with the Light that suffused him. His mind would not work; light and heat blinded it. The Light. In the midst of the void, the Light blinded his mind, stunned him with awe.

hi stʊɾ ɪn ə bɹɔd maʊntən pæs, sɝaʊndəd baɪ dʒæɡd blæk piks laɪk ðə tiθ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ɪt wɑz ɹil; hi wɑz ðɛɹ. hi fɛl ðə ɹɑks ʌndɝ ɪz buts, ði aɪsi bɹiz ɑn ɪz feɪs.

He stood in a broad mountain pass, surrounded by jagged black peaks like the teeth of the Dark One. It was real; he was there. He felt the rocks under his boots, the icy breeze on his face.

bæɾəl sɝaʊndəd hɪm, əɹ ðə teɪl ɛn ə bæɾəl. ɑɹmɝd mɛn ɑn ɑɹmɝd hɔɹsəz, ʃaɪnɪŋ stil dʌsti naʊ, slæʃt ən stæbd ət snɑɹlɪŋ tʃɹɑləks wildɪŋ spaɪkt æksiz ən saɪð-laɪk sɔɹdz. səm mɛn fɔɾ əfʊt, ðɛɹ hɔɹsəz daʊn, ən bɑɹɾɪd hɔɹsəz ɡæləp θɹu ðə faɪt wɪð ɛmpti sæɾəlz. feɪdz muvd əmʌŋ əm ɔl, naɪtblæk kloʊks hæŋɪŋ stɪl haʊɛvɝ ðɛɹ dɑɹk maʊns ɡæləpt, ən wɛɹɛvɝ ðɛɹ laɪɾitɪŋ sɔɹdz swʌŋ, mɛn daɪd. saʊn biɾ ət ɹænd, biɾ əɾ ɪm ən baʊns fɹəm ðə stʃɹeɪnʒnəs ðət hæɾ ɪm baɪ ðə θɹoʊt. ðə klæʃ ə stil əɡɛnst stil, ðə pæntɪŋ ən ɡɹʌntɪŋ ə mɛn ən tʃɹɑləks stʃɹaɪvɪŋ, ðə skɹimz ə mɛn ən tʃɹɑləks daɪɪŋ. oʊvɝ ðə dɪn, bænɝz weɪvd ɪn dʌst-fɪld ɛɹ. ðə blæk hɔk ə fæl dæɹə, ðə waɪt hɑɹɾ ə ʃaɪnɝ, ʌðɝz. ən tʃɹɑlɑk bænɝz. ɪn dʒʌs ðə lɪɾəl speɪs ɝaʊn ɪm i sɔ ðə hɔɹn skʌl ə ðə dɑvɑl, ðə blʌd-ɹɛd tʃɹaɪɾənt ə ðə koʊbəl, ði aɪɝn fɪst ə ðə deɪmən.

Battle surrounded him, or the tail end of battle. Armored men on armored horses, shining steel dusty now, slashed and stabbed at snarling Trollocs wielding spiked axes and scythe-like swords. Some men fought afoot, their horses down, and barded horses galloped through the fight with empty saddles. Fades moved among them all, nightblack cloaks hanging still however their dark mounts galloped, and wherever their lighteating swords swung, men died. Sound beat at Rand, beat at him and bounced from the strangeness that had him by the throat. The clash of steel against steel, the panting and grunting of men and Trollocs striving, the screams of men and Trollocs dying. Over the din, banners waved in dust-filled air. The Black Hawk of Fal Dara, the White Hart of Shienar, others. And Trolloc banners. In just the little space around him he saw the horned skull of the Dha'vol, the blood-red trident of the Ko'bal, the iron fist of the Dhai'mon.

jɛɾ ɪt wɑz ɪndid ðə teɪl ɛn ə bæɾəl, ə pɔzɪŋ, əz hjumənz ən tʃɹɑləks əlaɪk fɛl bæk tə ɹiɡɹup. nʌn sim tə noʊɾəs ɹænd əz ðeɪ peɪɾ ə fju læst stʃɹoʊks ən bɹoʊk əweɪ, ɡæləpɪŋ, əɹ ɹʌnɪŋ ɪn ə stæɡɝ, tə ði ɛnz ə ðə pæs.

Yet it was indeed the tail end of battle, a pausing, as humans and Trollocs alike fell back to regroup. None seemed to notice Rand as they paid a few last strokes and broke away, galloping, or running in a stagger, to the ends of the pass.

ɹænd faʊn hɪmsɛlf feɪsɪŋ ði ɛn ə ðə pæs wɛɹ ðə hjumənz wɝ ɹeɪ-fɔɹmɪŋ, pɛnəns stɝɪŋ bɪniθ ɡlimɪŋ lænsəpɔɪns. wundəd mɛn weɪvɝɾ ɪn ðɛɹ sæɾəlz. ɹaɪɾɝləs hɔɹsəz ɹɪɹɾ ən ɡæləpt. pleɪnli ðeɪ kəd nɑt stæn ənʌðɝ miɾɪŋ, jɛt dʒʌst əz pleɪnli ðeɪ ɹɛɾid ðɛmsɛlvz fəɹ wʌn faɪnəl tʃɑɹdʒ. səm ə ðɛm sɔ hɪm naʊ; mɛn stʊɾ ɪn ðɛɹ stɝəps tə pɔɪn ət hɪm. ðɛɹ ʃaʊts keɪm tə hɪm əz taɪni paɪpɪŋ.

Rand found himself facing the end of the pass where the humans were re-forming, pennants stirring beneath gleaming lancepoints. Wounded men wavered in their saddles. Riderless horses reared and galloped. Plainly they could not stand another meeting, yet just as plainly they readied themselves for one final charge. Some of them saw him now; men stood in their stirrups to point at him. Their shouts came to him as tiny piping.

stæɡɝɪŋ, hi tɝnd. ðə fɔɹsɪz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn fɪl ði ʌðɝ ɛn ə ðə pæs, bɹɪsəlɪŋ blæk paɪks ən spɪɹpɔɪns swɛlɪŋ ʌp ɑntu maʊntən sloʊps meɪd blækɝ stɪl baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪt mæs ə tʃɹɑləks ðət dwɔɹf ði ɑɹmi ʌv ʃaɪnɝ. feɪdz ɪn hʌnʒɹədz ɹoʊɾ əkɹɔs ðə fɹʌn ə ðə hɔɹd, ðə fɪɹs, mʌzəl feɪsəz ə tʃɹɑləks tɝnɪŋ əweɪ ɪn fɪɹ əz ðeɪ pæst, hjudʒ bɑɾiz pʊlɪŋ bæk tə meɪk weɪ. oʊvɝhɛd, dʒɹæɡkɝ wild ɑn lɛðɝi pɪnjənz, ʃɹiks tʃælənʒɪŋ ðə wɪnd. hæfmən sɔ hɪm naʊ, tu, pɔɪntəd, ən dʒɹæɡkɝ spʌn ən dʌv. tu. θɹi. sɪks ə ðɛm, kɹaɪɪŋ ʃɹɪli əz ðeɪ plʌməɾɪd təwɔɹd hɪm.

Staggering, he turned. The forces of the Dark One filled the other end of the pass, bristling black pikes and spearpoints swelling up onto mountain slopes made blacker still by the great mass of Trollocs that dwarfed the army of Shienar. Fades in hundreds rode across the front of the horde, the fierce, muzzled faces of Trollocs turning away in fear as they passed, huge bodies pulling back to make way. Overhead, Draghkar wheeled on leathery pinions, shrieks challenging the wind. Halfmen saw him now, too, pointed, and Draghkar spun and dove. Two. Three. Six of them, crying shrilly as they plummeted toward him.

hi stɛɹɾ ət ðɛm. hit fɪl hɪm, ðə bɝnɪŋ hiɾ ə ðə tʌtʃt sʌn. hi kəd si ðə dʒɹæɡkɝ klɪɹli, soʊlləs aɪz ɪn peɪl mɛnz feɪsəz ɑn wɪŋ bɑɾiz ðət hæd nʌθɪŋ ə hjumænɪɾi əbaʊt ðɛm. tɛɹəbəl hit. kɹæklɪŋ hit.

He stared at them. Heat filled him, the burning heat of the touched sun. He could see the Draghkar clearly, soulless eyes in pale men's faces on winged bodies that had nothing of humanity about them. Terrible heat. Crackling heat.

fɹəm ðə klɪɹ skaɪ laɪtnɪŋ keɪm, itʃ boʊl kɹɪsp ən ʃɑɹp, sɪɹɪŋ ɪz aɪz, itʃ boʊl stʃɹaɪkɪŋ ə wɪŋ blæk ʃeɪp. hʌntɪŋ kɹaɪz bɪkeɪm ʃɹiks ə dɛθ, ən tʃɑɹd fɔɹmz fɛl tə liv ðə skaɪ klin əɡɛn.

From the clear sky lightning came, each bolt crisp and sharp, searing his eyes, each bolt striking a winged black shape. Hunting cries became shrieks of death, and charred forms fell to leave the sky clean again.

ðə hit. ðə tɛɹəbəl hiɾ ə ðə laɪt.

The heat. The terrible heat of the Light.

hi fɛl tə hɪz niz; hi θɔɾ i kəd hɪɹ ɪz tɪɹz sɪzəlɪŋ ɑn ɪz tʃiks. "noʊ!" hi klʌtʃt ət tʌfs ʌv wɪɹi ɡɹæs fəɹ səm hoʊld ɑn ɹiæləɾi; ðə ɡɹæs bɝst ɪn fleɪm. "pliz, nuuuuuu!"

He fell to his knees; he thought he could hear his tears sizzling on his cheeks. "No!" He clutched at tufts of wiry grass for some hold on reality; the grass burst in flame. "Please, nooooooo!"

ðə wɪn ɹoʊz wɪð ɪz vɔɪs, haʊld wɪð ɪz vɔɪs, ɹɔɹd wɪð ɪz vɔɪs daʊn ðə pæs, wɪpɪŋ ðə fleɪmz tə ə wɔl ə faɪɝ ðət spɛɾ əweɪ fɹəm ɪm ən təwɔɹd ðə tʃɹɑlɑk hoʊs fæstɝ ðən ə hɔɹs kəd ɹʌn. faɪɝ bɝn ɪndə ðə tʃɹɑləks, ən ðə maʊntənz tʃɹɛmbəld wɪð ðɛɹ skɹimz, skɹimz ɔlmoʊst əz laʊɾ əz ðə wɪn ən ɪz vɔɪs.

The wind rose with his voice, howled with his voice, roared with his voice down the pass, whipping the flames to a wall of fire that sped away from him and toward the Trolloc host faster than a horse could run. Fire burned into the Trollocs, and the mountains trembled with their screams, screams almost as loud as the wind and his voice.

"ɪɾ əz tə ɛnd!"

"It has to end!"

hi biɾ ət ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɪð ɪz fɪst, ən ði ɝθ tɑld laɪk ə ɡɔŋ. hi bɹuzd ɪz hænz ɑn stoʊni sɔɪl, ən ði ɝθ tʃɹɛmbəld. ɹɪpəlz ɹæn θɹu ðə ɡɹaʊn əhɛɾ ə hɪm ɪn ɛvɛɹaɪzɪŋ weɪvz, weɪvz ə dɝɾ ən ɹɑk taʊɝɪŋ oʊvɝ tʃɹɑləks ən feɪdz, bɹeɪkɪŋ oʊvɝ əm əz ðə maʊntənz ʃæɾɝd ʌndɝ ðɛɹ huv fit. ə bɔɪlɪŋ mæs ə flɛʃ ən ɹʌbəl tʃɝn əkɹɔs ðə tʃɹɑlɑk ɑɹmi. wʌt wɑz lɛf stændɪŋ wɑz stɪl ə maɪɾi hoʊst, bʌt naʊ noʊ mɔɹ ðən twaɪs ðə hjumən ɑɹmi ɪn nʌmbɝz, ən mɪlɪŋ ɪn fɹaɪɾ ən kənfjuʒən.

He beat at the ground with his fist, and the earth tolled like a gong. He bruised his hands on stony soil, and the earth trembled. Ripples ran through the ground ahead of him in everrising waves, waves of dirt and rock towering over Trollocs and Fades, breaking over them as the mountains shattered under their hooved feet. A boiling mass of flesh and rubble churned across the Trolloc army. What was left standing was still a mighty host, but now no more than twice the human army in numbers, and milling in fright and confusion.

ðə wɪn daɪd. ðə skɹimz daɪd. ði ɝθ wɑz stɪl. dʌst ən smoʊk swɝl bæk daʊn ðə pæs tə sɝaʊn hɪm.

The wind died. The screams died. The earth was still. Dust and smoke swirled back down the pass to surround him.

"ðə laɪt blaɪn ju, bælzəmən! ðɪs əz tə ɛnd!"

"The Light blind you, Ba'alzamon! This has to end!"

ɪts nɑt hɪɹ.

IT IS NOT HERE.

ɪt wɑz nɑt ɹændz θɔt, meɪkɪŋ ɪz skʌl vaɪbɹeɪt.

It was not Rand's thought, making his skull vibrate.

əl teɪk noʊ pɑɹt. oʊnli ðə tʃoʊzən wʌn kən də wʌt mʌs bi dʌn, ɪf i wɪl.

I WILL TAKE NO PART. ONLY THE CHOSEN ONE CAN DO WHAT MUST BE DONE, IF HE WILL.

"wɛɹ?" hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə seɪ ɪt, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt stɑp hɪmsɛlf. "wɛɹ?"

"Where?" He did not want to say it, but he could not stop himself. "Where?"

ðə heɪz sɝaʊndɪŋ ɪm pɑɹɾəd, livɪŋ ə doʊm ə klɪɹ, klin ɛɹ tɛn spænz haɪ, wɔl baɪ bɪloʊɪŋ smoʊk ən dʌst. stɛps ɹoʊz bɪfɔɹ hɪm, itʃ stændɪŋ əloʊn ən ənsəpɔɹɾɪd, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ʌp ɪndə ðə mɝk ðəɾ əbskjʊɹd ðə sʌn.

The haze surrounding him parted, leaving a dome of clear, clean air ten spans high, walled by billowing smoke and dust. Steps rose before him, each standing alone and unsupported, stretching up into the murk that obscured the sun.

nɑt hɪɹ.

NOT HERE.

θɹu ðə mɪst, əz fɹəm ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ði ɝθ, keɪm ə kɹaɪ. "ðə laɪt wɪlz ɪt!" ðə ɡɹaʊn ɹʌmbəld wɪð ðə θʌndɝ ə hʊvz əz ðə fɔɹsɪz ə hjumənkaɪn lɔntʃt ðɛɹ læs tʃɑɹdʒ.

Through the mist, as from the far end of the earth, came a cry. "The Light wills it!" The ground rumbled with the thunder of hooves as the forces of humankind launched their last charge.

wɪðɪn ðə vɔɪd, hɪz maɪnd nu ə moʊmən ə pænɪk. ðə tʃɑɹdʒɪŋ hɔɹsmən kəd nɑt si hɪm ɪn ðə dʌst; ðɛɹ tʃɑɹdʒ wəd tʃɹæmpəl ɹaɪɾ oʊvɝ hɪm. ðə ɡɹeɪɾɝ pɑɹɾ ə hɪm ɪɡnɔɹd ðə ʃeɪkɪŋ ɡɹaʊn əz ə pɛɾi θɪŋ bɪniθ kənsɝn. dʌl æŋɡɝ dʒɹaɪvɪŋ ɪz fit, hi maʊntəd ðə fɝst stɛps. ɪts tə bi ɛndəd!

Within the void, his mind knew a moment of panic. The charging horsemen could not see him in the dust; their charge would trample right over him. The greater part of him ignored the shaking ground as a petty thing beneath concern. Dull anger driving his feet, he mounted the first steps. It has to be ended!

dɑɹknəs sɝaʊndəd hɪm, ði ʌɾɝ blæknəs ə toʊɾəl nʌθɪŋ. ðə stɛps wɝ stɪl ðɛɹ, hæŋɪŋ ɪn ðə blæk, ʌndɝ ɪz fiɾ ən əhɛd. wən i lʊk bæk, ðoʊz bɪhaɪnd wɝ ɡɔn, feɪɾəd əweɪ tə nʌθɪŋ, ɪndə ðə nʌθɪŋnəs ɝaʊn hɪm. bʌt ðə kɔɹd wɑz jɛt ðɛɹ, stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ bɪhaɪn hɪm, ðə ɡloʊɪŋ laɪn dwɪndəlɪŋ ən vænɪʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə dɪstəns. ɪt wɑz nɑt soʊ θɪk əz bɪfɔɹ, bʌɾ ɪt stɪl pʌlsd, pʌmpɪŋ stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪndə hɪm, pʌmpɪŋ laɪf, fɪlɪŋ ɪm wɪð ðə laɪt. hi klaɪmd.

Darkness surrounded him, the utter blackness of total nothing. The steps were still there, hanging in the black, under his feet and ahead. When he looked back, those behind were gone, faded away to nothing, into the nothingness around him. But the cord was yet there, stretching behind him, the glowing line dwindling and vanishing into the distance. It was not so thick as before, but it still pulsed, pumping strength into him, pumping life, filling him with the Light. He climbed.

ɪt sim fɝɛvɝ ðəɾ i klaɪmd. fɝɛvɝ, ən mɪnəts. taɪm stʊd stɪl ɪn nʌθɪŋnəs. taɪm ɹæn fæstɝ. hi klaɪmd əntɪl sʌɾənli ə dɔɹ stʊd bɪfɔɹ hɪm, ɪts sɝfəs ɹʌf ən splɪntɝɾ ən oʊld, ə dɔɹ wɛl-ɹɪmɛmbɝd. hi tʌtʃt ɪt, ən ɪt bɝs tə fɹæɡmɛns. waɪl ðeɪ stɪl fɛl, hi stɛp θɹu, bɪts ə ʃæɾɝd wʊd fɔlɪŋ fɹəm ɪz ʃoʊldɝz.

It seemed forever that he climbed. Forever, and minutes. Time stood still in nothingness. Time ran faster. He climbed until suddenly a door stood before him, its surface rough and splintered and old, a door well-remembered. He touched it, and it burst to fragments. While they still fell, he stepped through, bits of shattered wood falling from his shoulders.

ðə tʃeɪmbɝ, tu, wɑz əz i ɹɪmɛmbɝd, ðə mæd, stʃɹieɪɾɪd skaɪ bɪɑn ðə bælkəni, ðə mɛltəd wɔlz, ðə pɑlɪʃt teɪbəl, ðə tɛɹəbəl faɪɝpleɪs wɪð ɪts ɹɔɹɪŋ, hitləs fleɪmz. səm ə ðoʊz feɪsəz ðət meɪd ðə faɪɝpleɪs, ɹaɪðɪŋ ɪn tɔɹmɛnt, ʃɹikɪŋ ɪn saɪləns, tʌɡd əɾ ɪz mɛmɹi əz ɪf i nu ðɛm, bʌɾ i hɛl ðə vɔɪd kloʊs, floʊɾəd wɪðɪn hɪmsɛlf ɪn ɛmptinəs. hi wɑz əloʊn. wən i lʊkt ət ðə mɪɹɝ ɑn ðə wɔl, hɪz feɪs wɑz ðəɹ əz klɪɹ əz ɪf ɪt wɑz hɪm. ðəɹ ɪz kɑm ɪn ðə vɔɪd.

The chamber, too, was as he remembered, the mad, striated sky beyond the balcony, the melted walls, the polished table, the terrible fireplace with its roaring, heatless flames. Some of those faces that made the fireplace, writhing in torment, shrieking in silence, tugged at his memory as if he knew them, but he held the void close, floated within himself in emptiness. He was alone. When he looked at the mirror on the wall, his face was there as clear as if it was him. There is calm in the void.

"jɛs," bælzəmən sɛd fɹəm ɪn fɹʌn ə ðə faɪɝpleɪs, "aɪ θɔɾ eɪdʒɪnɝz ɡɹid wəɾ oʊvɝkʌm hɪm. bʌɾ ɪt meɪks noʊ dɪfɝəns ɪn ði ɛnd. ə lɔŋ sɝtʃ, bʌɾ ɛndəd naʊ. jə ɑɹ hɪɹ, ən aɪ noʊ ju."

"Yes," Ba'alzamon said from in front of the fireplace, "I thought Aginor's greed would overcome him. But it makes no difference in the end. A long search, but ended now. You are here, and I know you."

ɪn ðə mɪdst ə ðə laɪt ðə vɔɪd dʒɹɪftəd, ən ɪn ðə mɪdst ə ðə vɔɪd floʊɾəd ɹænd. hi ɹitʃt fəɹ ðə sɔɪl ə hɪz hoʊm, ən fɛl hɑɹd ɹɑk, ənjildɪŋ ən dʒɹaɪ, stoʊn wɪθaʊt pɪɾi, wɛɹ oʊnli ðə stʃɹɔŋ kəd sɝvaɪv, oʊnli ðoʊz əz hɑɹɾ əz ðə maʊntənz. "aɪ æm taɪɝɾ ə ɹʌnɪŋ." hi kəd nɑt bɪliv ɪz vɔɪs wɑz soʊ kɑm. "taɪɝɾ ə jə θɹɛɾənɪŋ maɪ fɹɛnz. əl ɹʌn noʊ mɔɹ." bælzəmən hæɾ ə kɔɹd, tu, hi sɔ. ə blæk kɔɹd, θɪkɝ baɪ fɑɹ ðən ɪz oʊn, soʊ waɪɾ ɪt ʃʊɾə dwɔɹf ðə hjumən bɑɾi, jɛt dwɔɹf baɪ bælzəmən, ɪnstɛd. itʃ pʌls əlɔŋ ðət blæk veɪn eɪt laɪt.

In the midst of the Light the void drifted, and in the midst of the void floated Rand. He reached for the soil of his home, and felt hard rock, unyielding and dry, stone without pity, where only the strong could survive, only those as hard as the mountains. "I am tired of running." He could not believe his voice was so calm. "Tired of you threatening my friends. I will run no more." Ba'alzamon had a cord, too, he saw. A black cord, thicker by far than his own, so wide it should have dwarfed the human body, yet dwarfed by Ba'alzamon, instead. Each pulse along that black vein ate light.

"ju θɪŋk ɪt meɪks ɛni dɪfɝəns, wɛðɝ jə ɹʌn əɹ steɪ?" ðə fleɪmz ə bælzəmənz maʊθ læft. ðə feɪsəz ɪn ðə hɑɹθ wɛpt ət ðɛɹ mæstɝz mɝθ. "ju hæv flɛd fɹəm mi mɛni taɪmz, ən itʃ taɪm aɪ ɹʌn jə daʊn ən meɪk jə it jəɹ pɹaɪd wɪð snaɪvəlɪŋ tɪɹz fəɹ spaɪs. mɛni taɪmz juv stʊɾ ən fɔt, ðən ɡɹoʊvəld ɪn dɪfit, bɛɡɪŋ mɝsi. juv ðɪs tʃɔɪs, wɝm, ən ðɪs tʃɔɪs oʊnli: nil ət maɪ fiɾ ən sɝv mi wɛl, ən əl ɡɪv jə paʊɝ əbʌv θɹoʊnz; əɹ bi tɑɹ vəlɑnz pʌpət ful ən skɹim waɪl jə ɑɹ ɡɹaʊn ɪndə ðə dʌst ə taɪm."

"You think it makes any difference, whether you run or stay?" The flames of Ba'alzamon's mouth laughed. The faces in the hearth wept at their master's mirth. "You have fled from me many times, and each time I run you down and make you eat your pride with sniveling tears for spice. Many times you have stood and fought, then groveled in defeat, begging mercy. You have this choice, worm, and this choice only: kneel at my feet and serve me well, and I will give you power above thrones; or be Tar Valon's puppet fool and scream while you are ground into the dust of time."

ɹænd ʃɪftəd, ɡlænsɪŋ bæk θɹu ðə dɔɹ əz ɪf sikɪŋ ə weɪ tə ɪskeɪp. lɛt ðə dɑɹk wʌn θɪŋk ðæt. bɪɑn ðə dɔɹweɪ wɑz stɪl ðə blæk ə nʌθɪŋ, splɪt baɪ ðə ʃaɪnɪŋ θɹɛd ðət ɹæn fɹəm ɪz bɑɾi. ən aʊt ðəɹ bælzəmənz hɛviɝ kɔɹd ɹæn əz wɛl, soʊ blæk ðəɾ ɪt stʊɾ aʊɾ ɪn ðə dɑɹk əz ɪf əɡɛnst snoʊ. ðə tu kɔɹdz bit laɪk hɑɹtvnz ɪn kaʊntɝtaɪm, əɡɛnst itʃ ʌðɝ, ðə laɪt bɛɹli ɹɪzɪstɪŋ ðə weɪvz ə dɑɹk.

Rand shifted, glancing back through the door as if seeking a way to escape. Let the Dark One think that. Beyond the doorway was still the black of nothing, split by the shining thread that ran from his body. And out there Ba'alzamon's heavier cord ran as well, so black that it stood out in the dark as if against snow. The two cords beat like heartveins in countertime, against each other, the light barely resisting the waves of dark.

"ðɛɹ ɑɹ ʌðɝ tʃɔɪsəz," ɹænd sɛd. "ðə wil wivz ðə pæɾɝn, nɑt ju. ɛvɹi tʃɹæp juv leɪd fəɹ mi, aɪ hæv ɪskeɪpt. aɪv ɪskeɪp jəɹ feɪdz ən tʃɹɑləks, ɪskeɪp jəɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. aɪ tʃɹæk jə hɪɹ, ən dɪstʃɹɔɪd jəɹ ɑɹmi ɑn ðə weɪ. jə də nɑt wiv ðə pæɾɝn."

"There are other choices," Rand said. "The Wheel weaves the Pattern, not you. Every trap you've laid for me, I have escaped. I've escaped your Fades and Trollocs, escaped your Darkfriends. I tracked you here, and destroyed your army on the way. You do not weave the Pattern."

bælzəmənz aɪz ɹɔɹd laɪk tu fɝnəsəz. hɪz lɪps dɪd nɑt muv, bʌt ɹænd θɔɾ i hɝɾ ə kɝs skɹimd əɾ eɪdʒɪnɝ. ðən ðə faɪɝz daɪd, ən ðəɾ ɔɹɾənɛɹi hjumən feɪs smaɪld əɾ ɪm ɪn ə weɪ ðət tʃɪld ivən θɹu ðə wɔɹmθ ə ðə laɪt.

Ba'alzamon's eyes roared like two furnaces. His lips did not move, but Rand thought he heard a curse screamed at Aginor. Then the fires died, and that ordinary human face smiled at him in a way that chilled even through the warmth of the Light.

"ʌðɝ ɑɹmiz kən bi ɹeɪzd, ful. ɑɹmiz juv nɑt dʒɹimd ʌv wɪl jɛt kʌm. ən jə tʃɹæk mi? jə slʌɡ ʌndɝ ə ɹɑk, tʃɹæk mi? aɪ bɪɡæn ðə sɛɾɪŋ ə jəɹ pæθ ðə deɪ jə wɝ bɔɹn, ə pæθ tə lid jə tə jəɹ ɡɹeɪv, əɹ hɪɹ. il əlaʊd tə fli, ən wʌn tə lɪv, tə spik ðə wɝdz ðət wəɾ ɛkoʊ daʊn ðə jɪɹz. dʒaɪn fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ, ə hɪɹoʊ," hi twɪstəd ðə wɝd tə ə snɪɹ, "hum aɪ peɪntəd laɪk ə ful ən sɛn tə ði oʊɡiɝ θɪŋkɪŋ i wɑz fɹi ʌv mi. ðə blæk ədʒɑ, ɹɪəlɪŋ laɪk wɝmz ɑn ðɛɹ bɛliz əkɹɔs ðə wɝl tə sɝtʃ jə aʊt. aɪ pʊl ðə stʃɹɪŋz ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit dænsəz ən θɪŋks ʃi kəntʃɹoʊlz ɪvɛns."

"Other armies can be raised, fool. Armies you have not dreamed of will yet come. And you tracked me? You slug under a rock, track me? I began the setting of your path the day you were born, a path to lead you to your grave, or here. Aiel allowed to flee, and one to live, to speak the words that would echo down the years. Jain Farstrider, a hero," he twisted the word to a sneer, "whom I painted like a fool and sent to the Ogier thinking he was free of me. The Black Ajah, wriggling like worms on their bellies across the world to search you out. I pull the strings and the Amyrlin Seat dances and thinks she controls events."

ðə vɔɪd tʃɹɛmbəld; heɪstəli ɹænd fɝmd ɪɾ əɡɛn. hi noʊz ɪɾ ɔl. hi kəɾ əv dʌn. ɪt kəd bi ðə weɪ hi sɛz. ðə laɪt wɔɹm ðə vɔɪd. daʊt kɹaɪɾ aʊɾ ən wɑz stɪld, tɪl oʊnli ðə sid ɹɪmeɪnd. hi stʃɹʌɡəld, nɑt noʊɪŋ wɛðɝ i wɑntəd tə bɛɹi ðə siɾ əɹ meɪk ɪt ɡɹoʊ. ðə vɔɪd stɛɾid, smɔlɝ ðən bɪfɔɹ, ən i floʊɾəd ɪn kɑm.

The void trembled; hastily Rand firmed it again. He knows it all. He could have done. It could be the way he says. The Light warmed the void. Doubt cried out and was stilled, till only the seed remained. He struggled, not knowing whether he wanted to bury the seed or make it grow. The void steadied, smaller than before, and he floated in calm.

bælzəmən sim tə noʊɾəs nʌθɪŋ. "ɪt mæɾɝz lɪɾəl ɪf aɪ hæv jə əlaɪv əɹ dɛd, ɪksɛp tə ju, ən tə wʌt paʊɝ jə maɪt hæv. jəl sɝv mi, əɹ jəɹ soʊl wɪl. bʌɾ aɪ wəd ɹæðɝ əv jə nil tə mi əlaɪv ðən dɛd. ə sɪŋɡəl fɪst ə tʃɹɑləks sɛn tə jəɹ vɪlədʒ wən aɪ cʊɾə sɛn ə θaʊzənd. wʌn dɑɹkfɹɛn tə feɪs jə wɛɹ ə hʌnʒɹəd kəd kʌm ɑn jə əslip. ən ju, ful, jə doʊn ivən noʊ ðɛm ɔl, niðɝ ðoʊz əhɛd, nɔɹ ðoʊz bɪhaɪnd, nɔɹ ðoʊz baɪ jəɹ saɪd. jə ɑɹ maɪn, hæv ɔlweɪz bɪn maɪn, maɪ dɔɡ ɑn ə liʃ, ən aɪ bɹɔt jə hɪɹ tə nil tə jəɹ mæstɝ əɹ daɪ ən lɛt jəɹ soʊl nil."

Ba'alzamon seemed to notice nothing. "It matters little if I have you alive or dead, except to you, and to what power you might have. You will serve me, or your soul will. But I would rather have you kneel to me alive than dead. A single fist of Trollocs sent to your village when I could have sent a thousand. One Darkfriend to face you where a hundred could come on you asleep. And you, fool, you don't even know them all, neither those ahead, nor those behind, nor those by your side. You are mine, have always been mine, my dog on a leash, and I brought you here to kneel to your master or die and let your soul kneel."

"aɪ dɪnaɪ ju. juv noʊ paʊɝ oʊvɝ mi, ən əl nɑt nil tə ju, əlaɪv əɹ dɛd."

"I deny you. You have no power over me, and I will not kneel to you, alive or dead."

"lʊk," bælzəmən sɛd. "lʊk." ənwɪlɪŋ, ɹænd jɛt tɝn ɪz hɛd.

"Look," Ba'alzamon said. "Look." Unwilling, Rand yet turned his head.

ɛɡwin stʊd ðɛɹ, ən nɪneɪiv, peɪl ən fɹaɪɾənd, wɪð flaʊɝz ɪn ðɛɹ hɛɹ. ən ənʌðɝ wʊmən, lɪɾəl oʊldɝ ðən ðə wɪzdəm, ɡɹeɪ-aɪɾ ən bjuɾəfəl, kloʊðd ɪn ə tu ɹɪvɝz dʒɹɛs, bɹaɪt blɑsəmz ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd ɹaʊn ðə nɛk.

Egwene stood there, and Nynaeve, pale and frightened, with flowers in their hair. And another woman, little older than the Wisdom, gray-eyed and beautiful, clothed in a Two Rivers dress, bright blossoms embroidered round the neck.

"mʌðɝ?" hi bɹiðd, ən ʃi smaɪld, ə hoʊpləs smaɪl. hɪz mʌðɝz smaɪl. "noʊ! maɪ mʌðɝ ɪz dɛd, ən ði ʌðɝ tu ɑɹ seɪf əweɪ fɹəm hɪɹ. aɪ dɪnaɪ ju!" ɛɡwin ən nɪneɪiv blɝd, bɪkeɪm wɑftɪŋ mɪst, dɪsəpeɪɾɪd. kɛɹi ælθɹ stɪl stʊd ðɛɹ, hɝ aɪz bɪɡ wɪð fɪɹ.

"Mother?" he breathed, and she smiled, a hopeless smile. His mother's smile. "No! My mother is dead, and the other two are safe away from here. I deny you!" Egwene and Nynaeve blurred, became wafting mist, dissipated. Kari al'Thor still stood there, her eyes big with fear.

"ʃi, ət list," bælzəmən sɛd, "ɪz maɪn tə də wɪð əz aɪ wɪl."

"She, at least," Ba'alzamon said, "is mine to do with as I will."

ɹænd ʃʊk ɪz hɛd. "aɪ dɪnaɪ ju." hi hæd tə fɔɹs ðə wɝdz aʊt. "ʃi ɪz dɛd, ən seɪf fɹəm jə ɪn ðə laɪt."

Rand shook his head. "I deny you." He had to force the words out. "She is dead, and safe from you in the Light."

hɪz mʌðɝz lɪps tʃɹɛmbəld. tɪɹz tʃɹɪkəl daʊn əɹ tʃiks; itʃ wʌn bɝn ɪm laɪk æsəd. "ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪv ɪz stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən i wʌns wɑz, maɪ sʌn," ʃi sɛd. "hɪz ɹitʃ ɪz lɔŋɡɝ. ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz əz ə hʌnid tʌŋ fəɹ ənwɛɹi soʊlz. maɪ sʌn. maɪ oʊnli, dɑɹlɪŋ sʌn. aɪ wəd spɛɹ jə ɪf aɪ kʊd, bʌt hiz maɪ mæstɝ, naʊ, hɪz wɪm, ðə lɔ ʌv maɪ ɛɡzɪstəns. aɪ kən bʌɾ oʊbeɪ hɪm, ən ɡɹɑvəl fəɹ ɪz feɪvɝ. oʊnli jə kən fɹi mi. pliz, maɪ sʌn. pliz hɛlp mi. hɛlp mi. hɛlp mi! pliz!"

His mother's lips trembled. Tears trickled down her cheeks; each one burned him like acid. "The Lord of the Grave is stronger than he once was, my son," she said. "His reach is longer. The Father of Lies has a honeyed tongue for unwary souls. My son. My only, darling son. I would spare you if I could, but he is my master, now, his whim, the law of my existence. I can but obey him, and grovel for his favor. Only you can free me. Please, my son. Please help me. Help me. Help me! PLEASE!"

ðə weɪl ɹɪpt aʊɾ ə hɝ əz bæɹəfeɪs feɪdz, peɪl ən aɪləs, kloʊzd ɹaʊnd. hɝ kloʊðz ɹɪpt əweɪ ɪn ðɛɹ blʌdləs hænz, hænz ðət wildɪd pɪnsɝz ən klæmps ən θɪŋz ðət stʌŋ ən bɝn ən wɪpt əɡɛnst əɹ neɪkəd flɛʃ. hɝ skɹim wəd nɑɾ ɛnd.

The wail ripped out of her as barefaced Fades, pale and eyeless, closed round. Her clothes ripped away in their bloodless hands, hands that wielded pincers and clamps and things that stung and burned and whipped against her naked flesh. Her scream would not end.

ɹændz skɹim ɛkoʊd hɝz. ðə vɔɪd bɔɪld ɪn ɪz maɪnd. hɪz sɔɹd wɑz ɪn ɪz hænd. nɑt ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd, bʌɾ ə bleɪɾ ə laɪt, ə bleɪɾ ə ðə laɪt. ivən əz i ɹeɪzd ɪt, ə faɪɝi waɪt boʊlt ʃɑt fɹəm ðə pɔɪnt, əz ɪf ðə bleɪɾ ɪtsɛlf hæd ɹitʃt aʊt. ɪt tʌtʃt ðə nɪɹəs feɪd, ən blaɪndɪŋ kɑnɛsəns fɪl ðə tʃeɪmbɝ, ʃaɪnɪŋ θɹu ðə hæfmən laɪk ə kændəl θɹu peɪpɝ, bɝnɪŋ θɹu ðɛm, blaɪndɪŋ ɪz aɪz tə ðə sin.

Rand's scream echoed hers. The void boiled in his mind. His sword was in his hand. Not the heron-mark blade, but a blade of light, a blade of the Light. Even as he raised it, a fiery white bolt shot from the point, as if the blade itself had reached out. It touched the nearest Fade, and blinding canescence filled the chamber, shining through the Halfmen like a candle through paper, burning through them, blinding his eyes to the scene.

fɹəm ðə mɪdst ə ðə bɹɪljəns, hi hɝɾ ə wɪspɝ. "θæŋk ju, maɪ sʌn. ðə laɪt. ðə blɛsɪd laɪt."

From the midst of the brilliance, he heard a whisper. "Thank you, my son. The Light. The blessed Light."

ðə flæʃ feɪɾəd, ən i wɑz əloʊn ɪn ðə tʃeɪmbɝ wɪð bælzəmən. bælzəmənz aɪz bɝn laɪk ðə pɪɾ ə dum, bʌɾ i ʃaɪd bæk fɹəm ðə sɔɹɾ əz ɪf ɪt tʃɹuli wɝ ðə laɪɾ ɪtsɛlf. "ful! jəl dɪstʃɹɔɪ jɝsɛlf! jə kænɑt wild ɪt soʊ, nɑt jɛt! nɑɾ əntɪl aɪ titʃ ju!"

The flash faded, and he was alone in the chamber with Ba'alzamon. Ba'alzamon's eyes burned like the Pit of Doom, but he shied back from the sword as if it truly were the Light itself. "Fool! You will destroy yourself! You cannot wield it so, not yet! Not until I teach you!"

"ɪɾ ɪz ɛndəd," ɹænd sɛd, ən i swʌŋ ðə sɔɹɾ ət bælzəmənz blæk kɔɹd.

"It is ended," Rand said, and he swung the sword at Ba'alzamon's black cord.

bælzəmən skɹimd əz ðə sɔɹd fɛl, skɹim tɪl ðə stoʊn wɔlz tʃɹɛmbəld, ən ði ɛnləs haʊl ɹidʌbəld əz ðə bleɪɾ ə laɪt sɛvɝd ðə kɔɹd. ðə kʌɾ ɛnz ɹɪbaʊndɪɾ əpɑɹɾ əz ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn ʌndɝ tɛnʃən. ði ɛn stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ ɪndə ðə nʌθɪŋnəs aʊtsaɪd bɪɡæn tə ʃɹɪvəl əz ɪt spɹæŋ əweɪ; ði ʌðɝ wɪp bæk ɪndə bælzəmən, hɝlɪŋ ɪm əɡɛns ðə faɪɝpleɪs. ðəɹ wɑz saɪlən læftɝ ɪn ðə saʊnləs ʃɹiks ə ðə tɔɹtʃɝd feɪsəz. ðə wɔlz ʃɪvɝɾ ən kɹækt; ðə flɔɹ hivd, ən tʃʌŋks ə stoʊn kɹæʃt tə ðə flɔɹ fɹəm ðə silɪŋ.

Ba'alzamon screamed as the sword fell, screamed till the stone walls trembled, and the endless howl redoubled as the blade of Light severed the cord. The cut ends rebounded apart as if they had been under tension. The end stretching into the nothingness outside began to shrivel as it sprang away; the other whipped back into Ba'alzamon, hurling him against the fireplace. There was silent laughter in the soundless shrieks of the tortured faces. The walls shivered and cracked; the floor heaved, and chunks of stone crashed to the floor from the ceiling.

əz ɔl bɹoʊk əpɑɹɾ ɝaʊn hɪm, ɹænd pɔɪntəd ðə sɔɹɾ ət bælzəmənz hɑɹt. "ɪɾ ɪz ɛndəd!"

As all broke apart around him, Rand pointed the sword at Ba'alzamon's heart. "It is ended!"

laɪt læns fɹəm ðə bleɪd, kɔɹʌskeɪɾɪŋ ɪn ə ʃaʊɝ ə faɪɝi spɑɹks laɪk dʒɹɑpləts ə moʊltən, waɪt mɛɾəl. weɪlɪŋ, bælzəmən θɹu ʌp ɪz ɑɹmz ɪn ə veɪn ɛfɝt tə ʃil hɪmsɛlf. fleɪmz ʃɹikt ɪn ɪz aɪz, dʒɔɪnɪŋ wɪð ʌðɝ fleɪmz əz ðə stoʊn ɪɡnaɪɾɪd, ðə stoʊn ə ðə kɹækɪŋ wɔlz, ðə stoʊn ə ðə pɪtʃɪŋ flɔɹ, ðə stoʊn ʃaʊɝɪŋ fɹəm ðə silɪŋ. ɹænd fɛl ðə bɹaɪt θɹɛɾ ətætʃt tə hɪm θɪnɪŋ, tɪl oʊnli ðə ɡloʊ ɪtsɛlf ɹɪmeɪnd, bʌɾ i stʃɹeɪn hɑɹɾɝ, nɑt noʊɪŋ wʌɾ i dɪd, əɹ haʊ, oʊnli ðət ðɪs hæd tə bi ɛndəd. ɪts tə bi ɛndəd!

Light lanced from the blade, coruscating in a shower of fiery sparks like droplets of molten, white metal. Wailing, Ba'alzamon threw up his arms in a vain effort to shield himself. Flames shrieked in his eyes, joining with other flames as the stone ignited, the stone of the cracking walls, the stone of the pitching floor, the stone showering from the ceiling. Rand felt the bright thread attached to him thinning, till only the glow itself remained, but he strained harder, not knowing what he did, or how, only that this had to be ended. It has to be ended!

faɪɝ fɪl ðə tʃeɪmbɝ, ə sɑləd fleɪm. hi kəd si bælzəmən wɪðɝɪŋ laɪk ə lif, hɪɹ ɪm haʊlɪŋ, fil ðə ʃɹiks ɡɹeɪɾɪŋ ɑn ɪz boʊnz. ðə fleɪm bɪkeɪm pjʊɹ, waɪt laɪt, bɹaɪɾɝ ðən ðə sʌn. ðən ðə læs flɪkɝ ə ðə θɹɛd wɑz ɡɔn, ən i wɑz fɔlɪŋ θɹu ɛnləs blæk ən bælzəmənz feɪɾɪŋ haʊl.

Fire filled the chamber, a solid flame. He could see Ba'alzamon withering like a leaf, hear him howling, feel the shrieks grating on his bones. The flame became pure, white light, brighter than the sun. Then the last flicker of the thread was gone, and he was falling through endless black and Ba'alzamon's fading howl.

sʌmθɪŋ stʃɹʌk ɪm wɪð tʃɹəmɛndəs fɔɹs, tɝnɪŋ ɪm tə dʒɛli, ən ðə dʒɛli ʃʊk ən skɹim fɹəm ðə faɪɝ ɹeɪdʒɪŋ ɪnsaɪd, ðə hʌŋɡɹi koʊl bɝnɪŋ wɪθaʊɾ ɛnd.

Something struck him with tremendous force, turning him to jelly, and the jelly shook and screamed from the fire raging inside, the hungry cold burning without end.

hi bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ə ðə sʌn, fɝst, muvɪŋ əkɹɔs ə klaʊdləs skaɪ, fɪlɪŋ ɪz ənblɪŋkɪŋ aɪz. ɪt sim tə ɡoʊ baɪ fɪts ən stɑɹts, stændɪŋ stɪl fəɹ deɪz, ðən dɑɹɾɪŋ əhɛɾ ɪn ə stʃɹik ə laɪt, dʒɝkɪŋ təwɔɹd ðə fɑɹ hɝaɪzən, deɪ fɔlɪŋ wɪð ɪt. laɪt. ðət ʃəd min sʌmθɪŋ. θɔt wɑz ə nu θɪŋ. aɪ kən θɪŋk. aɪ minz mi. peɪn keɪm nɛkst, ðə mɛmɹi ʌv ɹeɪdʒɪŋ fivɝ, ðə bɹuzəz wɛɹ ʃeɪkɪŋ tʃɪlz hæd θɹoʊn ɪm ɝaʊn laɪk ə ɹæɡ dɑl. ən ə stɪŋk. ə ɡɹisi, bɝn smɛl, fɪlɪŋ ɪz nɑstʃɹəlz, ən ɪz hɛd.

He became aware of the sun, first, moving across a cloudless sky, filling his unblinking eyes. It seemed to go by fits and starts, standing still for days, then darting ahead in a streak of light, jerking toward the far horizon, day falling with it. Light. That should mean something. Thought was a new thing. I can think. I means me. Pain came next, the memory of raging fever, the bruises where shaking chills had thrown him around like a rag doll. And a stink. A greasy, burned smell, filling his nostrils, and his head.

wɪð eɪkɪŋ mʌsəlz, hi hiv hɪmsɛlf oʊvɝ, pʊʃt ʌp tə hænz ən niz. ʌnkɑmpɹihɛndɪŋ, hi stɛɹɾ ət ði ɔɪli æʃəz ɪn wɪtʃ i hæd bɪn laɪɪŋ, æʃəz skæɾɝd ən smɪɹɾ oʊvɝ ðə stoʊn ə ðə hɪltɑp. bɪts ə dɑɹk ɡɹin klɔθ leɪ mɪkst ɪn ðə tʃɑɹ, ɛdʒ-blækən skɹæps ðət hæɾ ɪskeɪp ðə fleɪmz.

With aching muscles, he heaved himself over, pushed up to hands and knees. Bits of dark green cloth lay mixed in the char, edge-blackened scraps that had escaped the flames.

His stomach heaved and twisted. Trying to brush black streaks of ash from his clothes, he lurched away from the remains of the Forsaken. His hands flapped feebly, not making much headway. tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ, hi kɹɔl bækwɝdz ɑn ɪz bɛli əntɪl ðəɹ wɑz sɑləd stoʊn ʌndɝ ɪz aɪz, ðən flɑpt oʊvɝ ɑntu hɪz bæk, pæntɪŋ fəɹ bɹɛθ. wɪð ən ɛfɝɾ i fʌmbəld ɪz sɔɹd fɹəm ɪts skæbɝd. oʊnli ə fju æʃəz ɹɪmeɪn fɹəm ðə ɹɛd klɔθ. hɪz hænz ʃʊk wən i hɛld ɪɾ ʌp ɪn fɹʌn ə hɪz feɪs; ɪt tʊk boʊθ hænz. ɪt wɑz ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd - hɛɹən-mɑɹk? jɛs. tæm. maɪ fɑðɝ - bʌɾ oʊnli stil fəɹ ðæt. hi niɾəd θɹi weɪvɝɪŋ tʃɹaɪz tə ʃið ɪɾ əɡɛn. ɪt hæd bɪn sʌmθɪŋ ɛls. əɹ ðəɹ wɑz ənʌðɝ sɔɹd.

His arms and legs seemed to flail about more like long blades of grass than go as he wanted them to. Tottering, he fell against a tree, slamming against the trunk so hard that he grunted. Foliage rained on his head while he pressed his face to the rough bark, clutching to keep from falling. Egwene. He pushed himself away from the tree and hurried on. Almost immediately he tilted again, falling, but he forced his legs to work faster, to run into the fall so that he was staggering along at a good clip, all the while one step from falling flat on his face. Moving made his legs begin to obey him more. Slowly, he found himself running upright, arms pumping, long legs pulling him down the slope in leaps. He bounded into the clearing, half-filled now by the great oak marking the Green Man's grave. There was the white stone arch marked with the ancient symbol of the Aes Sedai, and the blackened, gaping pit where fire and wind had tried to trap Aginor and failed.

In the Age of Legends, Aginor was close behind the Kinslayer and Ishamael in power."

" 'ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən ɔl ðə fɔɹseɪkən,' " ɛɡwin kwoʊɾəd ɪn ə feɪnt, ənstɛɾi vɔɪs, " 'ɑɹ baʊn ɪn ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, baʊn baɪ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ. . . .' " ʃi dʒɹu ə ʃʌɾɝɪŋ bɹɛθ.

" 'The Dark One and all the Forsaken,' " Egwene quoted in a faint, unsteady voice, " 'are bound in Shayol Ghul, bound by the Creator. . . .' " She drew a shuddering breath.

"eɪdʒɪnɝ ən bælθəməl mʌst əv bɪn tʃɹæp nɪɹ ðə sɝfəs." mɔɪɹeɪn saʊndəɾ əz ɪf ʃi hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ɪkspleɪn ðɪs, ɪmpeɪʃən ət duɪŋ soʊ əɡɛn. "ðə pætʃ ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən wikən ɪnʌf tə fɹi ðɛm. lɛɾ əs bi θæŋkfəl noʊ mɔɹ ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɝ fɹid. ɪf ðeɪ hæd bɪn, wi wʊɾə sin ðɛm."

"Aginor and Balthamel must have been trapped near the surface." Moiraine sounded as if she had already explained this, impatient at doing so again. "The patch on the Dark One's prison weakened enough to free them. Let us be thankful no more of the Forsaken were freed. If they had been, we would have seen them."

"ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ," ɹænd sɛd. "eɪdʒɪnɝ ən bælθəməl ɑɹ dɛd, ən soʊ ɪz ʃaɪ' - "

"It doesn't matter," Rand said. "Aginor and Balthamel are dead, and so is Shai' - "

"ðə dɑɹk wʌn," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kʌɾ ɪm ɔf. ɪl əɹ nɑt, hɝ vɔɪs wɑz fɝm, ən əɹ dɑɹk aɪz kəmændɪŋ. "bɛst wi stɪl kɔl ɪm ðə dɑɹk wʌn. əɹ bælzəmən, ət list."

"The Dark One," the Aes Sedai cut him off. Ill or not, her voice was firm, and her dark eyes commanding. "Best we still call him the Dark One. Or Ba'alzamon, at least."

hi ʃɹʌɡd. "æz jə wɪʃ. bʌt hiz dɛd. ðə dɑɹk wʌnz dɛd. aɪ kɪl hɪm. aɪ bɝn ɪm wɪð. . . ." ðə ɹɛst ə mɛmɹi flʌɾəd bæk ðɛn, livɪŋ ɪz maʊθ hæŋɪŋ oʊpən. ðə wʌn paʊɝ. aɪ wildɪd ðə wʌn paʊɝ. noʊ mæn kæn. . . . hi lɪk lɪps ðət wɝ sʌɾənli dʒɹaɪ. ə ɡʌst ʌv wɪn swɝl fɔlən ən fɔlɪŋ livz ɝaʊn ðɛm, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz noʊ koʊldɝ ðən ɪz hɑɹt. ðeɪ wɝ lʊkɪŋ ət hɪm, ðə θɹi ʌv ðɛm. wɑtʃɪŋ. nɑɾ ivən blɪŋkɪŋ. hi ɹitʃt aʊt tə ɛɡwin, ən ðəɹ wɑz noʊ ɪmædʒəneɪʃən ɪn əɹ dʒɹɔɪŋ bæk ðɪs taɪm. "ɛɡwin?" ʃi tɝn əɹ feɪs əweɪ, ən i lɛɾ ɪz hæn dʒɹɑp.

He shrugged. "As you wish. But he's dead. The Dark One's dead. I killed him. I burned him with. . . ." The rest of memory flooded back then, leaving his mouth hanging open. The One Power. I wielded the One Power. No man can. . . . He licked lips that were suddenly dry. A gust of wind swirled fallen and falling leaves around them, but it was no colder than his heart. They were looking at him, the three of them. Watching. Not even blinking. He reached out to Egwene, and there was no imagination in her drawing back this time. "Egwene?" She turned her face away, and he let his hand drop.

əbɹʌpli ʃi flʌŋ əɹ ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɪm, bɛɹiɪŋ əɹ feɪs ɪn ɪz tʃɛst. "aɪm sɑɹi, ɹænd. aɪm sɑɹi. aɪ doʊn kɛɹ. tʃɹuli, aɪ doʊnt." hɝ ʃoʊldɝz ʃʊk. hi θɔt ʃi wɑz kɹaɪɪŋ. ɔkwɝdli pæɾɪŋ əɹ hɛɹ, hi lʊkt ət ði ʌðɝ tu wɪmən oʊvɝ ðə tɑp ə hɝ hɛd.

Abruptly she flung her arms around him, burying her face in his chest. "I'm sorry, Rand. I'm sorry. I don't care. Truly, I don't." Her shoulders shook. He thought she was crying. Awkwardly patting her hair, he looked at the other two women over the top of her head.

"ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz," nɪneɪiv sɛd sloʊli, "bʌt jə ɑɹ stɪl ɹænd ælθɹ ʌv ɛmənz fild. bʌt, ðə laɪt hɛlp mi, ðə laɪt hɛlp əs ɔl, jə ɑɹ tu deɪnʒɝəs, ɹænd." hi flɪntʃt fɹəm ðə wɪzdəmz aɪz, sæd, ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪŋ, ən ɔlɹɛɾi æksɛptɪŋ lɔs.

"The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills," Nynaeve said slowly, "but you are still Rand al'Thor of Emond's Field. But, the Light help me, the Light help us all, you are too dangerous, Rand." He flinched from the Wisdom's eyes, sad, regretting, and already accepting loss.

"wʌt hæpənd?" mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "tɛl mi ɛvɹiθɪŋ!"

"What happened?" Moiraine said. "Tell me everything!"

ən wɪð əɹ aɪz ɑn hɪm, kəmpɛlɪŋ, hi dɪd. hi wɑntəd tə tɝn əweɪ, tə meɪk ɪt ʃɔɹt, liv θɪŋz aʊt, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪz aɪz dʒɹu ɛvɹiθɪŋ fɹəm hɪm. tɪɹz ɹæn daʊn ɪz feɪs wən i keɪm tə kɛɹi ælθɹ. hɪz mʌðɝ. hi ɛmfəsaɪz ðæt. "hi hæd maɪ mʌðɝ. maɪ mʌðɝ!" ðəɹ wɑz sɪmpəθi ən peɪn ɑn nɪneɪivz feɪs, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪz aɪz dʒɹoʊv ɪm ɑn, tə ðə sɔɹɾ ə laɪt, tə sɛvɝɪŋ ðə blæk kɔɹd, ən ðə fleɪmz kənsumɪŋ bælzəmən. ɛɡwinz ɑɹmz taɪɾənd ɝaʊn ɪm əz ɪf ʃi wəd pʊl ɪm bæk fɹəm wʌt hæd hæpənd. "bʌɾ ɪt wɑzn mi," hi fɪnɪʃt. "ðə laɪt . . . pʊl mi əlɔŋ. ɪt wɑzn ɹɪli mi. dʌzn ðət meɪk ɛni dɪfɝəns?"

And with her eyes on him, compelling, he did. He wanted to turn away, to make it short, leave things out, but the Aes Sedai's eyes drew everything from him. Tears ran down his face when he came to Kari al'Thor. His mother. He emphasized that. "He had my mother. My mother!" There was sympathy and pain on Nynaeve's face, but the Aes Sedai's eyes drove him on, to the sword of Light, to severing the black cord, and the flames consuming Ba'alzamon. Egwene's arms tightened around him as if she would pull him back from what had happened. "But it wasn't me," he finished. "The Light . . . pulled me along. It wasn't really me. Doesn't that make any difference?"

"aɪ hæd səspɪʃənz fɹəm ðə fɝst," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "səspɪʃənz ɑɹ nɑt pɹuf, ðoʊ. æftɝ aɪ ɡeɪv jə ðə toʊkən, ðə kɔɪn, ən meɪd ðət bɑndɪŋ, jə ʃʊɾə bɪn wɪlɪŋ tə fɔl ɪn wɪð wʌtɛvɝ aɪ wɑntəd, bʌt jə ɹɪzɪstɪd, kwɛstʃənd. ðət toʊl mi sʌmθɪŋ, bʌt nɑɾ ɪnʌf. meɪnɛðɝən blʌd wɑz ɔlweɪz stʌbɝn, ən mɔɹ soʊ æftɝ æɛmən daɪɾ ən ɛldʒɹinz hɑɹt wɑz ʃæɾɝd. ðən ðəɹ wɑz bɛlə."

"I had suspicions from the first," Moiraine said. "Suspicions are not proof, though. After I gave you the token, the coin, and made that bonding, you should have been willing to fall in with Whatever I wanted, but you resisted, questioned. That told me something, but not enough. Manetheren blood was always stubborn, and more so after Aemon died and Eldrene's heart was shattered. Then there was Bela."

"bɛlə?" hi sɛd. nʌθɪŋ meɪks ɛni dɪfɝəns.

"Bela?" he said. Nothing makes any difference.

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ nɑɾəd. "æt wɑtʃ hɪl, bɛlə hæd noʊ niɾ ə mi tə klɛnz əɹ ə taɪɹədnəs; sʌmwʌn hæɾ ɔlɹɛɾi dʌn ɪt. ʃi cʊɾə aʊtʃɹʌn mændɑɹb, ðət naɪt. aɪ ʃʊɾə θɔɾ ə hu bɛlə kæɹid. wɪð tʃɹɑləks ɑn əɹ hilz, ə dʒɹæɡkɝ oʊvɝhɛd, ən ə hæfmən ðə laɪɾ əloʊn nu wɛɹ, haʊ jə mʌst əv fɪɹd ðəɾ ɛɡwin wəd bi lɛf bɪhaɪnd. jə niɾəd sʌmθɪŋ mɔɹ ðən jə hæɾ ɛvɝ niɾəd ɛniθɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ɪn jəɹ laɪf, ən jə ɹitʃt aʊt tə ðə wʌn θɪŋ ðət kəd ɡɪv ɪt tə ju. seɪɾɪn."

The Aes Sedai nodded. "At Watch Hill, Bela had no need of me to cleanse her of tiredness; someone had already done it. She could have outrun Mandarb, that night. I should have thought of who Bela carried. With Trollocs on our heels, a Draghkar overhead, and a Halfman the Light alone knew where, how you must have feared that Egwene would be left behind. You needed something more than you had ever needed anything before in your life, and you reached out to the one thing that could give it to you. Saidin."

hi ʃɪvɝd. hi fɛl soʊ koʊld ɪz fɪŋɡɝz hɝt. "ɪf aɪ nɛvɝ də ɪɾ əɡɛn, ɪf aɪ nɛvɝ tʌtʃ ɪɾ əɡɛn, aɪ woʊnt. . . ." hi kəd nɑt seɪ ɪt. ɡoʊ mæd. tɝn ðə læn ən pipəl ɝaʊn ɪm tə mædnəs. daɪ, ɹɑɾɪŋ waɪl i stɪl lɪvd.

He shivered. He felt so cold his fingers hurt. "If I never do it again, if I never touch it again, I won't. . . ." He could not say it. Go mad. Turn the land and people around him to madness. Die, rotting while he still lived.

"pɝhæps," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ɪt wəd bi mʌtʃ iziɝ ɪf ðəɹ wɑz sʌmwʌn tə titʃ ju, bʌɾ ɪt maɪt bi dʌn, wɪð ə səpɹim ɛfɝɾ ʌv wɪl."

"Perhaps," Moiraine said. "It would be much easier if there was someone to teach you, but it might be done, with a supreme effort of will."

"ju kən titʃ mi. ʃʊɹli, jə - " hi stɑpt wən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ʃʊk əɹ hɛd.

"You can teach me. Surely, you - " He stopped when the Aes Sedai shook her head.

"kæn ə kæt titʃ ə dɔɡ tə klaɪm tʃɹiz, ɹænd? kən ə fɪʃ titʃ ə bɝd tə swɪm? aɪ noʊ seɪaɪdɑɹ, bʌɾ aɪ kən titʃ jə nʌθɪŋ ə seɪɾɪn. ðoʊz u kəɾ ɑɹ θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz dɛd. pɝhæps jə ɑɹ stʌbɝn ɪnʌf, ðoʊ. pɝhæps jəɹ wɪl ɪz stʃɹɔŋ ɪnʌf."

"Can a cat teach a dog to climb trees, Rand? Can a fish teach a bird to swim? I know saidar, but I can teach you nothing of saidin. Those who could are three thousand years dead. Perhaps you are stubborn enough, though. Perhaps your will is strong enough."

ɛɡwin stʃɹeɪɾənd, waɪpɪŋ ɹɛɾənd aɪz wɪð ðə bæk ə hɝ hænd. ʃi lʊkt əz ɪf ʃi wɑntəd tə seɪ sʌmθɪŋ, bʌt wən ʃi oʊpən əɹ maʊθ, nʌθɪŋ keɪm aʊt. ət list ʃi ɪzən pʊlɪŋ əweɪ. ət list ʃi kən lʊk ət mi wɪθaʊt skɹimɪŋ.

Egwene straightened, wiping reddened eyes with the back of her hand. She looked as if she wanted to say something, but when she opened her mouth, nothing came out. At least she isn't pulling away. At least she can look at me without screaming.

"ði ʌðɝz?" hi sɛd.

"The others?" he said.

"læn tʊk əm ɪndə ðə kævɝn," nɪneɪiv sɛd. "ði aɪ ɪz ɡɔn, bʌt ðɛɹz sʌmθɪŋ ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ə ðə pul, ə kɹɪstəl kɑləm, ən stɛps tə ɹitʃ ɪt. mæt ən pɛɹɪn wɑntəd tə lʊk fəɹ jə fɝst - lɔɪəl dɪd, tu - bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. . . ." ʃi ɡlænst ət ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, tʃɹʌbəld. mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪtɝn əɹ lʊk kɑmli. "ʃi sɛd wi mʌsnt dɪstɝb jə waɪl jə wɝ. . . ."

"Lan took them into the cavern," Nynaeve said. "The Eye is gone, but there's something in the middle of the pool, a crystal column, and steps to reach it. Mat and Perrin wanted to look for you first - Loial did, too - but Moiraine said. . . ." She glanced at the Aes Sedai, troubled. Moiraine returned her look calmly. "She said we mustn't disturb you while you were. . . ."

hɪz θɹoʊt kənstʃɹɪktəɾ əntɪl i kəd hɑɹdli bɹið. wɪl ðeɪ tɝn ðɛɹ feɪsəz ðə weɪ ɛɡwin dɪd? wɪl ðeɪ skɹim ən ɹʌn əweɪ laɪk ɪm ə feɪd? mɔɪɹeɪn spoʊk əz ɪf ʃi dɪd nɑt noʊɾəs ðə blʌd dʒɹeɪnɪŋ fɹəm ɪz feɪs.

His throat constricted until he could hardly breathe. Will they turn their faces the way Egwene did? Will they scream and run away like I'm a Fade? Moiraine spoke as if she did not notice the blood draining from his face.

"ðɛɹ wɑz ə væst əmaʊn ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪn ði aɪ. ivən ɪn ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, fju cʊɾə tʃænəl soʊ mʌtʃ əneɪɾɪd wɪθaʊt biɪŋ dɪstʃɹɔɪd. vɛɹi fju."

"There was a vast amount of the One Power in the Eye. Even in the Age of Legends, few could have channeled so much unaided without being destroyed. Very few."

"ju toʊl ðɛm?" hi sɛd hɔɹsli. "ɪf ɛvɹibɑɾi noʊz. . . ."

"You told them?" he said hoarsely. "If everybody knows. . . ."

"oʊnli læn," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd dʒɛnli. "hi mʌs noʊ. ən nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin, fəɹ wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ ən wʌt ðəl bɪkʌm. ði ʌðɝz əv noʊ nid, jɛt."

"Only Lan," Moiraine said gently. "He must know. And Nynaeve and Egwene, for what they are and what they will become. The others have no need, yet."

"waɪ nɑt?" ðə ɹæsp ɪn ɪz θɹoʊt meɪɾ ɪz vɔɪs hɑɹʃ. "ju wɪl bi wɑntɪŋ tə dʒɛntəl mi, woʊn ju? ɪzən ðət wʌɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ də tə mɛn u kən wil ðə paʊɝ? tʃeɪnʒ əm soʊ ðeɪ kænt? meɪk əm seɪf? tɑm sɛd mɛn u hæv bɪn dʒɛntəl daɪ kəz ðeɪ stɑp wɑntɪŋ tə lɪv. waɪ ɑɹən jə tɔkɪŋ əbaʊt teɪkɪŋ mi tə tɑɹ vəlɑn tə bi dʒɛntəld?"

"Why not?" The rasp in his throat made his voice harsh. "You will be wanting to gentle me, won't you? Isn't that what Aes Sedai do to men who can wield the Power? Change them so they can't? Make them safe? Thom said men who have been gentled die because they stop wanting to live. Why aren't you talking about taking me to Tar Valon to be gentled?"

"ju ɑɹ tɑvɝən," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd. "pɝhæps ðə pæɾɝn əz nɑt fɪnɪʃt wɪð ju."

"You are ta'veren," Moiraine replied. "Perhaps the Pattern has not finished with you."

ɹænd sæɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt. "ɪn ðə dʒɹimz bælzəmən sɛd tɑɹ vəlɑn ən ði æmɪɝlɪn sit wəd tʃɹaɪ tə juz mi. hi neɪm neɪmz, ən aɪ ɹɪmɛmbɝ ðɛm, naʊ. ɹɑoʊlɪn dɑɹksbeɪn ən ɡɛɹ əmɑlɑsən. jʊɹiən stoʊnboʊ. dɑviən. lɑɡən." ðə læst wɑz ðə hɑɹɾəst ʌv ɔl tə seɪ. nɪneɪiv wɛn peɪl ən ɛɡwin ɡæspt, bʌɾ i pɹɛst ɑn æŋɡɹəli. "ɛvɹi wʌn ə fɔls dʒɹæɡən. doʊn tʃɹaɪ tə dɪnaɪ ɪt. wɛl, aɪ woʊn bi juzd. aɪm nɑɾ ə tul jə kən θɹoʊ ɑn ðə mɪɾən hip wən ɪts wɔɹn aʊt."

Rand sat up straight. "In the dreams Ba'alzamon said Tar Valon and the Amyrlin Seat would try to use me. He named names, and I remember them, now. Raolin Darksbane and Guaire Amalasan. Yurian Stonebow. Davian. Logain." The last was the hardest of all to say. Nynaeve went pale and Egwene gasped, but he pressed on angrily. "Every one a false Dragon. Don't try to deny it. Well, I won't be used. I am not a tool you can throw on the midden heap when it's worn out."

"ə tul meɪd fəɹ ə pɝpəs ɪz nɑt dɪmin baɪ biɪŋ juz fəɹ ðət pɝpəs," mɔɪɹeɪnz vɔɪs wɑz əz hɑɹʃ əz ɪz oʊn, "bʌɾ ə mæn u bɪlivz ðə fɑðɝ ə laɪz dɪminz hɪmsɛlf. jə seɪ jəl nɑt bi juzd, ən ðən jə lɛt ðə dɑɹk wʌn sɛt jəɹ pæθ laɪk ə haʊn sɛn æftɝ ə ɹæbət baɪ hɪz mæstɝ."

"A tool made for a purpose is not demeaned by being used for that purpose," Moiraine's voice was as harsh as his own, "but a man who believes the Father of Lies demeans himself. You say you will not be used, and then you let the Dark One set your path like a hound sent after a rabbit by his master."

hɪz fɪsts klɛntʃt, ən i tɝn ɪz hɛɾ əweɪ. ɪt wɑz tu kloʊz tə ðə θɪŋz bælzəmən hæd sɛd. "aɪ æm noʊ wʌnz haʊnd. dʒju hɪɹ mi? noʊ wʌnz!"

His fists clenched, and he turned his head away. It was too close to the things Ba'alzamon had said. "I am no one's hound. Do you hear me? No one's!"

lɔɪəl ən ði ʌðɝz əpɪɹɾ ɪn ði ɑɹtʃ, ən ɹænd skɹæmbəl tə hɪz fit, lʊkɪŋ ət mɔɪɹeɪn.

Loial and the others appeared in the arch, and Rand scrambled to his feet, looking at Moiraine.

"ðeɪ wɪl nɑt noʊ," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd, "əntɪl ðə pæɾɝn meɪks ɪt soʊ."

"They will not know," the Aes Sedai said, "until the Pattern makes it so."

ðən ɪz fɹɛnz wɝ kʌmɪŋ kloʊs. læn lɛd ðə weɪ, lʊkɪŋ əz hɑɹɾ əz ɛvɝ bʌt stɪl sʌmwʌt ðə wɝs fəɹ wɛɹ. hi hæd wʌn ə nɪneɪivz bændədʒəz ɝaʊn ɪz tɛmpəlz, ən ə stɪfbækt weɪ ʌv wɔkɪŋ. bɪhaɪn hɪm, lɔɪəl kæɹiɾ ə lɑɹdʒ ɡoʊl tʃɛst, ɔɹnətli wɝkt ən tʃeɪst wɪð sɪlvɝ. noʊ wʌn bʌɾ ən oʊɡiɝ cʊɾə lɪftəɾ ɪɾ əneɪɾɪd. pɛɹɪn hæɾ ɪz ɑɹmz ɹæpt ɝaʊn ə bɪɡ bʌndəl ə foʊldəd waɪt klɔθ, ən mæt wɑz kʌpɪŋ wʌɾ əpɪɹd tə bi fɹæɡmɛns ə pɑɾɝi ɪn ɪz tu hænz.

Then his friends were coming close. Lan led the way, looking as hard as ever but still somewhat the worse for wear. He had one of Nynaeve's bandages around his temples, and a stiffbacked way of walking. Behind him, Loial carried a large gold chest, ornately worked and chased with silver. No one but an Ogier could have lifted it unaided. Perrin had his arms wrapped around a big bundle of folded white cloth, and Mat was cupping what appeared to be fragments of pottery in his two hands.

"soʊ jəɹ əlaɪv æftɝ ɔl." mæt læft. hɪz feɪs dɑɹkənd, ən i dʒɝkt ɪz hɛɾ ət mɔɪɹeɪn. "ʃi wʊdn lɛɾ əs lʊk fəɹ ju. sɛd wi hæd tə faɪn aʊt wʌt ði aɪ wɑz haɪɾɪŋ. aɪɾ əv ɡɔn ɛniweɪ, bʌt nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin saɪɾəd wɪð əɹ ən ɔlmoʊs θɹu mi θɹu ði ɑɹtʃ."

"So you're alive after all." Mat laughed. His face darkened, and he jerked his head at Moiraine. "She wouldn't let us look for you. Said we had to find out what the Eye was hiding. I'd have gone anyway, but Nynaeve and Egwene sided with her and almost threw me through the arch."

"jɔɹ hɪɹ, naʊ," pɛɹɪn sɛd, "ænd nɑt tu bædli biɾən əbaʊt, baɪ ðə lʊk ə ju." hɪz aɪz dɪd nɑt ɡloʊ, bʌt ði aɪɹəsɪz wɝ ɔl jɛloʊ, naʊ. "ðæts ði ɪmpɔɹɾənt θɪŋ. jəɹ hɪɹ, ən wɝ dʌn wɪð wʌt wi keɪm fɔɹ, wʌtɛvɝ ɪt wɑz. mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛz wɝ dʌn, ən wi kən ɡoʊ. hoʊm, ɹænd. ðə laɪt bɝn mi, bʌɾ aɪ wɑnə ɡoʊ hoʊm."

"You're here, now," Perrin said, "and not too badly beaten about, by the look of you." His eyes did not glow, but the irises were all yellow, now. "That's the important thing. You're here, and we're done with what we came for, Whatever it was. Moiraine Sedai says we're done, and we can go. Home, Rand. The Light burn me, but I want to go home."

"ɡʊd tə si jə əlaɪv, ʃifɝɾɝ," læn sɛd ɡɹʌflaɪ. "aɪ si jə hʌŋ ɑntu jəɹ sɔɹd. meɪbi jəl lɝn tə juz ɪt, naʊ." ɹænd fɛlt ə sʌɾən bɝst ʌv əfɛkʃən fəɹ ðə wɔɹɾɝ; læn nu, bʌɾ ɑn ðə sɝfəs ət list, nʌθɪŋ hæd tʃeɪnʒd. hi θɔt ðət pɝhæps, fəɹ læn, nʌθɪŋ hæd tʃeɪnʒd ɪnsaɪɾ iðɝ.

"Good to see you alive, sheepherder," Lan said gruffly. "I see you hung onto your sword. Maybe you'll learn to use it, now." Rand felt a sudden burst of affection for the Warder; Lan knew, but on the surface at least, nothing had changed. He thought that perhaps, for Lan, nothing had changed inside either.

"aɪ mʌst seɪ," lɔɪəl sɛd, sɛɾɪŋ ðə tʃɛs daʊn, "ðæt tʃɹævlɪŋ wɪð tɑvɝən əz tɝn aʊt tə bi ivən mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ ðən aɪ ɪkspɛktəd." hɪz ɪɹz twɪtʃt vaɪələnli. "ɪf ɪt bɪkʌmz ɛni mɔɹ ɪntʃɹəstɪŋ, əl ɡoʊ bæk tə stɛɾɪŋ ʃæŋktaɪ ɪmiɾiətli, kənfɛs ɛvɹiθɪŋ tə ɛldɝ heɪmən, ən nɛvɝ liv maɪ bʊks əɡɛn." sʌɾənli ði oʊɡiɝ ɡɹɪnd, ðət waɪd maʊθ splɪɾɪŋ ɪz feɪs ɪn tu. "ɪɾ ɪz soʊ ɡʊd tə si ju, ɹænd ælθɹ. ðə wɔɹɾɝ ɪz ði oʊnli wʌn ə ðiz θɹi hu kɛɹz mʌtʃ əɾ ɔl fəɹ bʊks, ən i woʊn tɔk. wʌt hæpən tə ju? wi ɔl ɹæn ɔf ən hɪɾ ɪn ðə wʊdz əntɪl mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛn læn tə faɪn ʌs, bʌt ʃi wəd nɑt lɛɾ əs lʊk fəɹ ju. waɪ wɝ jə ɡɔn soʊ lɔŋ, ɹænd?"

"I must say," Loial said, setting the chest down, "that traveling with ta'veren has turned out to be even more interesting than I expected." His ears twitched violently. "If it becomes any more interesting, I will go back to Stedding Shangtai immediately, confess everything to Elder Haman, and never leave my books again." Suddenly the Ogier grinned, that wide mouth splitting his face in two. "It is so good to see you, Rand al'Thor. The Warder is the only one of these three who cares much at all for books, and he won't talk. What happened to you? We all ran off and hid in the woods until Moiraine Sedai sent Lan to find us, but she would not let us look for you. Why were you gone so long, Rand?"

"aɪ ɹæn ən ɹæn," hi sɛd sloʊli, "əntɪl aɪ fɛl daʊn ə hɪl ən hɪt maɪ hɛɾ ɑn ə ɹɑk. aɪ θɪŋk aɪ hɪɾ ɛvɹi ɹɑk ɑn ðə weɪ daʊn." ðət ʃəɾ ɪkspleɪn ɪz bɹuzəz. hi tʃɹaɪd tə wɑtʃ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin, tu, bʌt ðɛɹ feɪsəz nɛvɝ tʃeɪnʒd. "wɛn aɪ keɪm tə, aɪ wɑz lɔst, ən faɪnəli aɪ stʌmbəl bæk hɪɹ. aɪ θɪŋk eɪdʒɪnɝ ɪz dɛd, bɝnd. aɪ faʊn səm æʃəz, ən pisəz ə hɪz kloʊk."

"I ran and ran," he said slowly, "until I fell down a hill and hit my head on a rock. I think I hit every rock on the way down." That should explain his bruises. He tried to watch the Aes Sedai, and Nynaeve and Egwene, too, but their faces never changed. "When I came to, I was lost, and finally I stumbled back here. I think Aginor is dead, burned. I found some ashes, and pieces of his cloak."

ðə laɪz saʊndəd hɑloʊ ɪn ɪz ɪɹz. hi kəd nɑɾ ʌndɝstænd waɪ ðeɪ dɪd nɑt læf wɪð skɔɹn ən dɪmæn ðə tʃɹuθ, bʌɾ ɪz fɹɛnz nɑɾəd, æksɛptɪŋ, ən meɪd sɪmpəθɛɾɪk saʊnz əz ðeɪ ɡæðɝɾ ɝaʊn ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə ʃoʊ hɝ wʌt ðeɪ hæd faʊnd.

The lies sounded hollow in his ears. He could not understand why they did not laugh with scorn and demand the truth, but his friends nodded, accepting, and made sympathetic sounds as they gathered around the Aes Sedai to show her what they had found.

"hɛlp mi ʌp," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin lɪftəɾ əɹ əntɪl ʃi wɑz sɪɾɪŋ; ðeɪ hæd tə səpɔɹɾ əɹ ivən ðɛn.

"Help me up," Moiraine said. Nynaeve and Egwene lifted her until she was sitting; they had to support her even then.

"haʊ kəd ðiz θɪŋz bi ɪnsaɪd ði aɪ," mæt æskt, "wɪθaʊt biɪŋ dɪstʃɹɔɪd laɪk ðət ɹɑk?"

"How could these things be inside the Eye," Mat asked, "without being destroyed like that rock?"

"ðeɪ wɝ nɑt pʊt ðəɹ tə bi dɪstʃɹɔɪd," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɛd kɝtli, ən fɹaʊn əweɪ ðɛɹ kwɛstʃənz waɪl ʃi tʊk ðə pɑɾɝi fɹæɡməns, blæk ən waɪɾ ən ʃaɪni, fɹəm mæt.

"They were not put there to be destroyed," the Aes Sedai said curtly, and frowned away their questions while she took the pottery fragments, black and white and shiny, from Mat.

ðeɪ sim laɪk ɹʌbəl tə ɹænd, bʌt ʃi fɪɾəd əm təɡɛðɝ dɛfli ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn bɪsaɪd hɝ, meɪkɪŋ ə pɝfək sɝkəl ðə saɪz ʌv ə mænz hænd. ði eɪntʃən sɪmbəl ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðə fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn dʒɔɪnd wɪð ðə dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ, blæk saɪɾɪŋ waɪt. fəɹ ə moʊmən mɔɪɹeɪn oʊnli lʊkt əɾ ɪt, hɝ feɪs ənɹiɾəbəl, ðən ʃi tʊk ðə naɪf fɹəm əɹ bɛlt ən hændəɾ ɪt tə læn, nɑɾɪŋ tə ðə sɝkəl.

They seemed like rubble to Rand, but she fitted them together deftly on the ground beside her, making a perfect circle the size of a man's hand. The ancient symbol of the Aes Sedai, the Flame of Tar Valon joined with the Dragon's Fang, black siding white. For a moment Moiraine only looked at it, her face unreadable, then she took the knife from her belt and handed it to Lan, nodding to the circle.

ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛpɝeɪɾəd aʊt ðə lɑɹdʒəs pis, ðən ɹeɪz ðə naɪf haɪ ən bɹɔɾ ɪt daʊn wɪð ɔl ɪz maɪt. ə spɑɹk flu, ðə fɹæɡmən lɛpt wɪð ðə fɔɹs ə ðə bloʊ, ən ðə bleɪd snæpt wɪð ə ʃɑɹp kɹæk. hi ɪɡzæmən ðə stʌmp lɛft ətætʃt tə ðə hɪlt, ðən tɔst ɪɾ əsaɪd. "ðə bɛst stil fɹəm tɛɹ," hi sɛd dʒɹaɪli.

The Warder separated out the largest piece, then raised the knife high and brought it down with all his might. A spark flew, the fragment leaped with the force of the blow, and the blade snapped with a sharp crack. He examined the stump left attached to the hilt, then tossed it aside. "The best steel from Tear," he said dryly.

mæt snætʃt ðə fɹæɡmɛn ʌp ən ɡɹʌntɪd, ðən ʃoʊɾ ɪɾ ɝaʊnd. ðəɹ wɑz noʊ mɑɹk ɑn ɪt.

Mat snatched the fragment up and grunted, then showed it around. There was no mark on it.

"kwəndɪlɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "hɑɹtstoʊn. noʊ wʌn əz bɪn eɪbəl tə meɪk ɪt sɪns ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ən ivən ðən ɪt wɑz meɪɾ oʊnli fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst pɝpəs. wʌns meɪd, nʌθɪŋ kən bɹeɪk ɪt. nɑt ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪtsɛlf wildɪd baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst ɛɛs sədaɪ hu ɛvɝ lɪvd eɪɾəd baɪ ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl sɑŋɡɹil ɛvɝ meɪd. ɛni paʊɝ dɝɛktəɾ əɡɛns hɑɹtstoʊn oʊnli meɪks ɪt stʃɹɔŋɝ."

"Cuendillar," Moiraine said. "Heartstone. No one has been able to make it since the Age of Legends, and even then it was made only for the greatest purpose. Once made, nothing can break it. Not the One Power itself wielded by the greatest Aes Sedai who ever lived aided by the most powerful sa'angreal ever made. Any power directed against heartstone only makes it stronger."

"ðɛn haʊ . . . ?" mæts dʒɛstʃɝ wɪð ðə pis i hɛl tʊk ɪn ði ʌðɝ bɪts ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊnd.

"Then how . . . ?" Mat's gesture with the piece he held took in the other bits on the ground.

"ðɪs wɑz wʌn ə ðə sɛvən silz ɑn ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. mæt dʒɹɑp ðə pis əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪkʌm waɪt-hɑt. fəɹ ə moʊmənt, pɛɹɪnz aɪz sim tə ɡloʊ əɡɛn. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ kɑmli bɪɡæn ɡæðɝɪŋ ðə fɹæɡməns.

"This was one of the seven seals on the Dark One's prison," Moiraine said. Mat dropped the piece as if it had become white-hot. For a moment, Perrin's eyes seemed to glow again. The Aes Sedai calmly began gathering the fragments.

"ɪt dʌzn mæɾɝ ɛnimɔɹ," ɹænd sɛd. hɪz fɹɛnz lʊkt əɾ ɪm ɑdli, ən i wɪʃt i hæd kɛpt ɪz maʊθ ʃʌt.

"It doesn't matter anymore," Rand said. His friends looked at him oddly, and he wished he had kept his mouth shut.

"ʌv kɔɹs," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd. bʌt ʃi kɛɹfəli pʊɾ ɔl ðə pisəz ɪndə hɝ paʊtʃ. "bɹɪŋ mi ðə tʃɛst." lɔɪəl lɪftəɾ ɪt kloʊsɝ.

"Of course," Moiraine replied. But she carefully put all the pieces into her pouch. "Bring me the chest." Loial lifted it closer.

ðə flæɾənd kjub ʌv ɡoʊld ən sɪlvɝ əpɪɹd tə bi sɑləd, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪz fɪŋɡɝz fɛlt əkɹɔs ði ɪntʃɹəkət wɝk, pɹɛsɪŋ, ən wɪð ə sʌɾən klɪk ə tɑp flʌŋ bæk əz ɪf ɑn spɹɪŋz. ə kɝld, ɡoʊl hɔɹn nɛsəld wɪðɪn. dɪspaɪɾ ɪts ɡlim, ɪt sim pleɪn bɪsaɪd ðə tʃɛs ðət hɛld ɪt. ði oʊnli mɑɹkɪŋz wɝ ə laɪn ə sɪlvɝ skɹɪpt ɪnleɪɾ ɝaʊn ðə maʊθ ə ðə bɛl. mɔɪɹeɪn lɪftəd ðə hɔɹn aʊɾ əz ɪf lɪftɪŋ ə beɪb. "ðɪs mʌs bi kæɹid tə ɪljən," ʃi sɛd sɔfli.

The flattened cube of gold and silver appeared to be solid, but the Aes Sedai's fingers felt across the intricate work, pressing, and with a sudden click a top flung back as if on springs. A curled, gold horn nestled within. Despite its gleam, it seemed plain beside the chest that held it. The only markings were a line of silver script inlaid around the mouth of the bell. Moiraine lifted the horn out as if lifting a babe. "This must be carried to Illian," she said softly.

"ɪljən!" pɛɹɪn ɡɹaʊld. "ðæts ɔlmoʊs tə ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, nɪɹli əz fɑɹ saʊθ ə hoʊm əz wəɹ nɔɹθ naʊ."

"Illian!" Perrin growled. "That's almost to the Sea of Storms, nearly as far south of home as we are north now."

"ɪz ɪt . . . ?" lɔɪəl stɑp tə kætʃ ɪz bɹɛθ. "kæn ɪt bi . . . ?"

"Is it . . . ?" Loial stopped to catch his breath. "Can it be . . . ?"

"ju kən ɹid ði oʊl tʌŋ?" mɔɪɹeɪn æskt, ən wən i nɑɾəd, ʃi hændəɾ ɪm ðə hɔɹn.

"You can read the Old Tongue?" Moiraine asked, and when he nodded, she handed him the horn.

ði oʊɡiɝ tʊk ɪɾ əz dʒɛnli əz ʃi hæd, dɛləkətli tʃɹeɪsɪŋ ðə skɹɪpt wɪð wʌn bɹɔd fɪŋɡɝ. hɪz aɪz wɛnt waɪɾɝ ən waɪɾɝ, ən ɪz ɪɹz stʊɾ ʌp stʃɹeɪt. "tiə mi ɑveɪən mɔɹaɪɾɪn ɪeɪn veɪɾɪn," hi wɪspɝd. "ðə ɡɹeɪv ɪz noʊ bɑɹ tə maɪ kɔl."

The Ogier took it as gently as she had, delicately tracing the script with one broad finger. His eyes went wider and wider, and his ears stood up straight. "Tia mi aven Moridin isainde vadin," he whispered. "The grave is no bar to my call."

"ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ." fəɹ wʌns ðə wɔɹɾɝ əpɪɹd tʃɹuli ʃeɪkən; ðəɹ wɑz ə tʌtʃ ʌv ɑ ɪn ɪz vɔɪs.

"The Horn of Valere." For once the Warder appeared truly shaken; there was a touch of awe in his voice.

ət ðə seɪm taɪm nɪneɪiv sɛɾ ɪn ə ʃeɪki vɔɪs, "tə kɔl ðə hɪɹoʊz ə ði eɪdʒəz bæk fɹəm ðə dɛd tə faɪt ðə dɑɹk wʌn."

At the same time Nynaeve said in a shaky voice, "To call the heroes of the Ages back from the dead to fight the Dark One."

"bɝn mi!" mæt bɹiðd.

"Burn me!" Mat breathed.

lɔɪəl ɹɛvɝənli leɪd ðə hɔɹn bæk ɪn ɪts ɡoʊldən nɛst. "aɪ bɪɡɪn tə wʌndɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld wɑz meɪɾ əɡɛns ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst nid ðə wɝld wəɾ ɛvɝ feɪs, bʌt wɑz ɪt meɪd fəɹ ðə jus tə wɪtʃ . . . wi . . . pʊɾ ɪt, əɹ tə ɡɑɹd ðiz θɪŋz? kwɪkli, ðə læst, ʃoʊ ɪt tə mi."

Loial reverently laid the horn back in its golden nest. "I begin to wonder," Moiraine said. "The Eye of the World was made against the greatest need the world would ever face, but was it made for the use to which . . . we . . . put it, or to guard these things? Quickly, the last, show it to me."

æftɝ ðə fɝs tu, ɹænd kəɾ ʌndɝstæn pɛɹɪnz ɹɪlʌktəns. læn ən ði oʊɡiɝ tʊk ðə bʌndəl ʌv waɪt klɔθ fɹəm ɪm wən i hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, ən ənfoʊldəɾ ɪt bɪtwin ðɛm. ə lɔŋ, waɪt bænɝ spɹɛɾ aʊt, lɪftɪŋ ɑn ði ɛɹ. ɹænd kəɾ oʊnli stɛɹ. ðə hoʊl θɪŋ simd ʌv ə pis, niðɝ woʊvən, nɔɹ daɪd, nɔɹ peɪntəd. ə fɪɡjɝ laɪk ə sɝpənt, skeɪld ɪn skɑɹləɾ ən ɡoʊld, ɹæn ði ɪntaɪɝ lɛŋθ, bʌɾ ɪt hæd skeɪld lɛɡz, ən fit wɪð faɪv lɔŋ, ɡoʊldən klɔz ɑn itʃ, ən ə ɡɹeɪt hɛd wɪð ə ɡoʊldən meɪn ən aɪz laɪk ðə sʌn. ðə stɝɪŋ ə ðə bænɝ meɪɾ ɪt sim tə muv, skeɪlz ɡlɪɾɝɪŋ laɪk pɹɛʃəs mɛɾəlz ən dʒɛmz, əlaɪv, ən i ɔlmoʊs θɔɾ i kəd hɪɹ ɪt ɹɔɹ dɪfaɪəns.

After the first two, Rand could understand Perrin's reluctance. Lan and the Ogier took the bundle of white cloth from him when he hesitated, and unfolded it between them. A long, white banner spread out, lifting on the air. Rand could only stare. The whole thing seemed of a piece, neither woven, nor dyed, nor painted. A figure like a serpent, scaled in scarlet and gold, ran the entire length, but it had scaled legs, and feet with five long, golden claws on each, and a great head with a golden mane and eyes like the sun. The stirring of the banner made it seem to move, scales glittering like precious metals and gems, alive, and he almost thought he could hear it roar defiance.

"wʌɾ ɪz ɪt?" hi sɛd.

"What is it?" he said.

mɔɪɹeɪn ænsɝd sloʊli. "ðə bænɝ ə ðə lɔɹɾ ə ðə mɔɹnɪŋ wən i lɛd ðə fɔɹsɪz ə laɪɾ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ. ðə bænɝ ə luz θɝɪn tɛləmən. ðə bænɝ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən." lɔɪəl ɔlmoʊs dʒɹɑpt ɪz ɛnd.

Moiraine answered slowly. "The banner of the Lord of the Morning when he led the forces of light against the Shadow. The banner of Lews Therin Telamon. The banner of the Dragon." Loial almost dropped his end.

"bɝn mi!" mæt sɛd feɪnli.

"Burn me!" Mat said faintly.

"wi wɪl teɪk ðiz θɪŋz wɪð əs wən wi ɡoʊ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ðeɪ wɝ nɑt pʊt hɪɹ baɪ tʃæns, ən aɪ mʌs noʊ mɔɹ." hɝ fɪŋɡɝz bɹʌʃt əɹ paʊtʃ, wɛɹ ðə pisəz ə ðə ʃæɾɝd sil wɝ. "ɪɾ ɪz tu leɪɾ ɪn ðə deɪ fəɹ stɑɹɾɪŋ naʊ. wɪl ɹɛst, ən it, bʌt wɪl liv ɝli. ðə blaɪɾ ɪz ɔl ɝaʊn hɪɹ, nɑɾ əz əlɔŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝ, ən stʃɹɔŋ. wɪθaʊt ðə ɡɹin mæn, ðɪs pleɪs kænɑt hoʊld lɔŋ. lemi daʊn," ʃi toʊl nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin. "aɪ mʌst ɹɛst."

"We will take these things with us when we go," Moiraine said. "They were not put here by chance, and I must know more." Her fingers brushed her pouch, where the pieces of the shattered seal were. "It is too late in the day for starting now. We will rest, and eat, but we will leave early. The Blight is all around here, not as along the Border, and strong. Without the Green Man, this place cannot hold long. Let me down," she told Nynaeve and Egwene. "I must rest."

ɹænd bɪkeɪm əwɛɹ ʌv wʌɾ i hæd bɪn siɪŋ ɔl əlɔŋ, bʌt nɑt noʊɾɪsɪŋ. dɛd, bɹaʊn livz fɔlɪŋ fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪɾ oʊk. dɛd livz ɹʌslɪŋ θɪk ɑn ðə ɡɹaʊn ɪn ðə bɹiz, bɹaʊn mɪkst wɪð pɛɾəlz dʒɹɑp fɹəm θaʊzənz ə flaʊɝz. ðə ɡɹin mæn hæd hɛl bæk ðə blaɪt, bʌɾ ɔlɹɛɾi ðə blaɪt wɑz kɪlɪŋ wʌɾ i hæd meɪd.

Rand became aware of what he had been seeing all along, but not noticing. Dead, brown leaves falling from the great oak. Dead leaves rustling thick on the ground in the breeze, brown mixed with petals dropped from thousands of flowers. The Green Man had held back the Blight, but already the Blight was killing what he had made.

"ɪɾ ɪz dʌn, ɪzən ɪt?" hi æsk mɔɪɹeɪn. "ɪɾ ɪz fɪnɪʃt."

"It is done, isn't it?" he asked Moiraine. "It is finished."

ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tɝn əɹ hɛɾ ɑn ɪts pɪloʊ ʌv kloʊks. hɝ aɪz simd əz dip əz ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld. "wi hæv dʌn wʌt wi keɪm hɪɹ tə du. fɹəm hɪɹ jə meɪ lɪv jəɹ laɪf əz ðə pæɾɝn wivz. it, ðən slip, ɹænd ælθɹ. slip, ən dʒɹim ə hoʊm."

The Aes Sedai turned her head on its pillow of cloaks. Her eyes seemed as deep as the Eye of the World. "We have done what we came here to do. From here you may live your life as the Pattern weaves. Eat, then sleep, Rand al'Thor. Sleep, and dream of home."


tʃæptɝ fɪftiθɹi


CHAPTER 53

ðə wil tɝnz


The Wheel Turns

dɔn ɹɪvil dɛvəsteɪʃən ɪn ðə ɡɹin mænz ɡɑɹɾən. ðə ɡɹaʊnd wɑz θɪk wɪð fɔlən livz, ɔlmoʊs ni-dip ɪn pleɪsəz. ɔl ðə flaʊɝz wɝ ɡɔn ɪksɛpt ə fju klɪŋɪŋ dɛspɝətli tə ði ɛdʒ ə ðə klɪɹɪŋ. lɪɾəl kəd ɡɹoʊ ɪn ðə sɔɪl ʌndɝ ən oʊk, bʌɾ ə θɪn sɝkəl ə flaʊɝz ən ɡɹæs sɛntɝɾ ɑn ðə θɪk tʃɹʌŋk əbʌv ðə ɡɹin mænz ɡɹeɪv. ði oʊk ɪtsɛlf ɹɪteɪn oʊnli hæf ɪts livz, ən ðət wɑz fɑɹ mɔɹ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ tʃɹi hæd, əz ɪf səm ɹɛmnən ə ðə ɡɹin mæn stɪl fɔt tə hoʊl ðɛɹ. ðə kul bɹizɪz hæd daɪd, ɹipleɪs baɪ ə ɡɹoʊɪŋ stɪki hit, ðə bʌɾɝflaɪz wɝ ɡɔn, ðə bɝdz saɪlənt. ɪt wɑz ə saɪlənt ɡɹup u pɹipɛɹd tə liv.

Dawn revealed devastation in the Green Man's garden. The ground was thick with fallen leaves, almost knee-deep in places. All the flowers were gone except a few clinging desperately to the edge of the clearing. Little could grow in the soil under an oak, but a thin circle of flowers and grass centered on the thick trunk above the Green Man's grave. The oak itself retained only half its leaves, and that was far more than any other tree had, as if some remnant of the Green Man still fought to hold there. The cool breezes had died, replaced by a growing sticky heat, the butterflies were gone, the birds silent. It was a silent group who prepared to leave.

ɹænd klaɪmd ɪndə ðə beɪz sæɾəl wɪð ə sɛns ə lɔs. ɪt ʃʊdn bi ðɪs weɪ. blʌɾ ən æʃəz, wi wʌn!

Rand climbed into the bay's saddle with a sense of loss. It shouldn't be this way. Blood and ashes, we won!

"aɪ wɪʃ i hæd faʊn ɪz ʌðɝ pleɪs," ɛɡwin sɛɾ əz ʃi maʊntəd bɛlə. ə lɪɾɝ, fæʃən baɪ læn, wɑz slʌŋ bɪtwin ðə ʃæɡi mɛɹ ən ɑldib, tə kæɹi mɔɪɹeɪn; nɪneɪiv wəd ɹaɪd bɪsaɪd wɪð ðə waɪt mɛɹz ɹeɪnz. ðə wɪzdəm dʒɹɑpt əɹ aɪz wɛnɛvɝ ʃi sɔ læn ɡlæns ət hɝ, əvɔɪɾɪŋ ɪz ɡeɪz; ðə wɔɹɾɝ lʊkt əɾ əɹ wɛnɛvɝ əɹ aɪz wɝ əvɝɾəd, bʌɾ i wəd nɑt spik tə hɝ. noʊ wʌn hæd tə æsk u ɛɡwin mɛnt.

"I wish he had found his other place," Egwene said as she mounted Bela. A litter, fashioned by Lan, was slung between the shaggy mare and Aldieb, to carry Moiraine; Nynaeve would ride beside with the white mare's reins. The Wisdom dropped her eyes whenever she saw Lan glance at her, avoiding his gaze; the Warder looked at her whenever her eyes were averted, but he would not speak to her. No one had to ask who Egwene meant.

"ɪɾ ɪz nɑt ɹaɪt," lɔɪəl sɛd, stɛɹɪŋ ət ði oʊk. ði oʊɡiɝ wɑz ði oʊnli wʌn stɪl nɑt maʊntəd. "ɪɾ ɪz nɑt ɹaɪt ðət tʃɹibɹəðɝ ʃəd fɔl tə ðə blaɪt." hi hændəd ðə ɹeɪnz ə hɪz bɪɡ hɔɹs tə ɹænd. "nɑt ɹaɪt."

"It is not right," Loial said, staring at the oak. The Ogier was the only one still not mounted. "It is not right that Treebrother should fall to the Blight." He handed the reins of his big horse to Rand. "Not right."

læn oʊpən ɪz maʊθ əz ði oʊɡiɝ wɔk tə ðə ɡɹeɪɾ oʊk. mɔɪɹeɪn, laɪɪŋ ɑn ðə lɪɾɝ, wikli ɹeɪzd əɹ hænd, ən ðə wɔɹɾɝ sɛd nʌθɪŋ.

Lan opened his mouth as the Ogier walked to the great oak. Moiraine, lying on the litter, weakly raised her hand, and the Warder said nothing.

bɪfɔɹ ði oʊk, lɔɪəl nɛlt, kloʊzɪŋ ɪz aɪz ən stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ aʊɾ ɪz ɑɹmz. ðə tʌfs ɑn ɪz ɪɹz stʊd stʃɹeɪɾ əz i lɪftəɾ ɪz feɪs tə ðə skaɪ. ən i sæŋ.

Before the oak, Loial knelt, closing his eyes and stretching out his arms. The tufts on his ears stood straight as he lifted his face to the sky. And he sang.

ɹænd kəd nɑt seɪ ɪf ðəɹ wɝ wɝdz, əɹ ɪf ɪt wɑz pjʊɹ sɔŋ. ɪn ðət ɹʌmbəlɪŋ vɔɪs ɪt wɑz əz ɪf ði ɝθ sæŋ, jɛɾ i wɑz ʃʊɹ i hɝd ðə bɝdz tʃɹɪlɪŋ əɡɛn, ən spɹɪŋ bɹizɪz saɪɪŋ sɔfli, ən ðə saʊn ə bʌɾɝflaɪ wɪŋz. lɔst ɪn ðə sɔŋ, hi θɔɾ ɪt læstəɾ oʊnli mɪnəts, bʌt wən lɔɪəl loʊɝɾ ɪz ɑɹmz ən oʊpən ɪz aɪz, hi wɑz sɝpɹaɪz tə si ðə sʌn stʊd wɛl əbʌv ðə hɝaɪzən. ɪt hæd bɪn tʌtʃɪŋ ðə tʃɹiz wən ði oʊɡiɝ bɪɡæn. ðə livz stɪl ɑn ði oʊk simd ɡɹinɝ, ən mɔɹ fɝmli ətætʃt ðən bɪfɔɹ. ðə flaʊɝz ɛnsɝkəlɪŋ ɪt stʊd stʃɹeɪɾɝ, ðə mɔɹnɪŋstɑɹz waɪɾ ən fɹɛʃ, ðə lʌvɝsknɑts ə stʃɹɔŋ kɹɪmzən.

Rand could not say if there were words, or if it was pure song. In that rumbling voice it was as if the earth sang, yet he was sure he heard the birds trilling again, and spring breezes sighing softly, and the sound of butterfly wings. Lost in the song, he thought it lasted only minutes, but when Loial lowered his arms and opened his eyes, he was surprised to see the sun stood well above the horizon. It had been touching the trees when the Ogier began. The leaves still on the oak seemed greener, and more firmly attached than before. The flowers encircling it stood straighter, the morningstars white and fresh, the loversknots a strong crimson.

mɑpɪŋ swɛt fɹəm ɪz bɹɔd feɪs, lɔɪəl ɹoʊz ən tʊk ɪz ɹeɪnz fɹəm ɹænd. hɪz lɔŋ aɪbɹaʊz dʒɹupt, əbæʃt, əz ɪf ðeɪ maɪt θɪŋk i hæd bɪn ʃoʊɪŋ ɔf. "aɪv nɛvɝ sʌŋ soʊ hɑɹd bɪfɔɹ. aɪ kəd nɑɾ əv dʌn ɪɾ ɪf sʌmθɪŋ ə tʃɹibɹəðɝ wɑz nɑt stɪl ðɛɹ. maɪ tʃɹi sɔŋz də nɑɾ əv ɪz paʊɝ." wən i sɛɾəld hɪmsɛlf ɪn ɪz sæɾəl, ðəɹ wɑz sæɾəsfækʃən ɪn ðə lʊk i ɡeɪv ði oʊk ən ðə flaʊɝz. "ðɪs lɪɾəl speɪs, ət list, wɪl nɑt sɪŋk ɪndə ðə blaɪt. ðə blaɪt wɪl nɑɾ əv tʃɹibɹəðɝ."

Mopping sweat from his broad face, Loial rose and took his reins from Rand. His long eyebrows drooped, abashed, as if they might think he had been showing off. "I've never sung so hard before. I could not have done it if something of Treebrother was not still there. My Tree Songs do not have his power." When he settled himself in his saddle, there was satisfaction in the look he gave the oak and the flowers. "This little space, at least, will not sink into the Blight. The Blight will not have Treebrother."

"ju ɑɹ ə ɡʊd mæn, oʊɡiɝ," læn sɛd.

"You are a good man, Ogier," Lan said.

lɔɪəl ɡɹɪnd. "aɪ wɪl teɪk ðəɾ əz ə kɑmpləmənt, bʌɾ aɪ də nɑt noʊ wʌɾ ɛldɝ heɪmən wəd seɪ."

Loial grinned. "I will take that as a compliment, but I do not know what Elder Haman would say."

ðeɪ ɹoʊɾ ɪn ə sɪŋɡəl faɪl, wɪð mæt bɪhaɪn ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɛɹ i kəd juz ɪz baʊ tə ɪfɛkt ɪf niɾəd, ən pɛɹɪn bɹɪŋɪŋ ʌp ðə ɹɪɹ wɪð ɪz æks əkɹɔs ðə pɑməl ə hɪz sæɾəl. ðeɪ kɹɛstəɾ ə hɪl, ən ɪn ən aɪɛblɪŋk ðə blaɪt wɑz ɔl ɝaʊn ðɛm, twɪstəɾ ən ɹɑɾɪd ɪn vɪɹələn ɹeɪnboʊ hjuz. ɹænd lʊkt oʊvɝ ɪz ʃoʊldɝ, bʌt ðə ɡɹin mænz ɡɑɹɾən wɑz noʊwɛɹ tə bi sin. oʊnli ðə blaɪt stʃɹɛtʃɪŋ bɪhaɪn əm əz bɪfɔɹ. jɛɾ i θɔt, dʒʌs fəɹ ə moʊmənt, ðəɾ i sɔ ðə taʊɝɪŋ tɑp ə ði oʊk tʃɹi, ɡɹin ən lʌʃ, bɪfɔɹ ɪt ʃɪmɝɾ ən wɑz ɡɔn. ðən ðəɹ wɑz oʊnli ðə blaɪt.

They rode in a single file, with Mat behind the Warder where he could use his bow to effect if needed, and Perrin bringing up the rear with his axe across the pommel of his saddle.
