They crested a hill, and in an eyeblink the Blight was all around them, twisted and rotted in virulent rainbow hues. Rand looked over his shoulder, but the Green Man's garden was nowhere to be seen. Only the Blight stretching behind them as before. Yet he thought, just for a moment, that he saw the towering top of the oak tree, green and lush, before it shimmered and was gone. Then there was only the Blight.

hi hæf ɪkspɛktəd ðeɪ wəɾ əv tə faɪt ðɛɹ weɪ aʊɾ əz ðeɪ fɔt ðɛɹ weɪ ɪn, bʌt ðə blaɪt wɑz əz kwaɪəɾ ən stɪl əz dɛθ. nɑɾ ə sɪŋɡəl bɹæntʃ tʃɹɛmbəld əz ɪf tə læʃ ət ðɛm, nʌθɪŋ skɹimd əɹ haʊld, niðɝ nɪɹbaɪ nɔɹ ɪn ðə dɪstəns. ðə blaɪt sim tə kɹaʊtʃ, nɑt tə paʊns, bʌɾ əz ɪf ɪt hæd bɪn stʃɹʌk ə ɡɹeɪt bloʊ ən weɪɾəd fəɹ ðə nɛks tə fɔl. ivən ðə sʌn wɑz lɛs ɹɛd.

He half expected they would have to fight their way out as they fought their way in, but the Blight was as quiet and still as death. Not a single branch trembled as if to lash at them, nothing screamed or howled, neither nearby nor in the distance. The Blight seemed to crouch, not to pounce, but as if it had been struck a great blow and waited for the next to fall. Even the sun was less red.

wən ðeɪ pæs ðə nɛkləs ə leɪks, ðə sʌn hʌŋ nɑt fɑɹ pæst ɪts zinəθ. læn kɛpt əm wɛl əweɪ fɹəm ðə leɪks ən dɪd nɑɾ ivən lʊk ət ðɛm, bʌt ɹænd θɔt ðə sɛvən taʊɝz sim tɔlɝ ðən wən i fɝst sɔ ðɛm. hi wɑz ʃʊɹ ðə dʒæɡd tɑps wɝ fɝðɝ fɹəm ðə ɡɹaʊnd, ən əbʌv əm sʌmθɪŋ ɔlmoʊst sin, simləs taʊɝz ɡlimɪŋ ɪn ðə sʌn, ən bænɝz wɪð ɡoʊldən kɹeɪnz flaɪɪŋ ɑn ðə wɪnd. hi blɪŋkt ən stɛɹd, bʌt ðə taʊɝz ɹəfjuz tə vænɪʃ kəmplitli. ðeɪ wɝ ðəɹ ət ði ɛdʒ ə vɪʒən əntɪl ðə blaɪt hɪd ðə leɪks wʌns mɔɹ.

When they passed the necklace of lakes, the sun hung not far past its zenith. Lan kept them well away from the lakes and did not even look at them, but Rand thought the seven towers seemed taller than when he first saw them. He was sure the jagged tops were further from the ground, and above them something almost seen, seamless towers gleaming in the sun, and banners with Golden Cranes flying on the wind. He blinked and stared, but the towers refused to vanish completely. They were there at the edge of vision until the Blight hid the lakes once more.

bɪfɔɹ sʌnsɛt ðə wɔɹɾɝ tʃoʊz ə kæmpsaɪt, ən mɔɪɹeɪn hæd nɪneɪiv ən ɛɡwin hɛlp əɹ ʌp tə sɛt wɔɹdz. ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪspɝɾ ɪn ði ʌðɝ wɪmənz ɪɹz bɪfɔɹ ʃi bɪɡæn. nɪneɪiv hɛzɪteɪɾɪd, bʌt wən mɔɪɹeɪn kloʊzd əɹ aɪz, ɔl θɹi wɪmən dɪd soʊ təɡɛðɝ.

Before sunset the Warder chose a campsite, and Moiraine had Nynaeve and Egwene help her up to set wards. The Aes Sedai whispered in the other women's ears before she began. Nynaeve hesitated, but when Moiraine closed her eyes, all three women did so together.

ɹænd sɔ mæt ən pɛɹɪn stɛɹɪŋ, ən wʌndɝd haʊ ðeɪ kəd bi sɝpɹaɪzd. ɛvɹi wʊmən ɪz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, hi θɔt mɝθləsli. ðə laɪt hɛlp mi, soʊ æm aɪ. bliknəs hɛld ɪz tʌŋ.

Rand saw Mat and Perrin staring, and wondered how they could be surprised. Every woman is an Aes Sedai, he thought mirthlessly. The Light help me, so am I. Bleakness held his tongue.

"waɪ ɪz ɪt soʊ dɪfɹənt?" pɛɹɪn æskt əz ɛɡwin ən ðə wɪzdəm hɛlp mɔɪɹeɪn tə hɝ bɛd. "ɪt filz. . . ." hɪz θɪk ʃoʊldɝz ʃɹʌɡd əz ɪf i kəd nɑt faɪn ðə wɝd.

"Why is it so different?" Perrin asked as Egwene and the Wisdom helped Moiraine to her bed. "It feels. . . ." His thick shoulders shrugged as if he could not find the word.

"wi stʃɹʌk ə maɪɾi bloʊ ət ðə dɑɹk wʌn," mɔɪɹeɪn ɹɪplaɪd, sɛɾəlɪŋ hɝsɛlf wɪð ə saɪ. "ðə ʃædoʊ wɪl bi ə lɔŋ taɪm ɹəkʌvɝɪŋ."

"We struck a mighty blow at the Dark One," Moiraine replied, settling herself with a sigh. "The Shadow will be a long time recovering."

"haʊ?" mæt dɪmændəd. "wʌt dɪd wi du?"

"How?" Mat demanded. "What did we do?"

"slip," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "wi ɑɹ nɑɾ aʊɾ ə ðə blaɪt jɛt."

"Sleep," Moiraine said. "We are not out of the Blight yet."

bʌt ðə nɛks mɔɹnɪŋ, stɪl nʌθɪŋ tʃeɪnʒd ðət ɹænd kəd si. ðə blaɪt feɪɾəd əz ðeɪ ɹoʊd saʊθ, ʌv kɔɹs. twɪstəd tʃɹiz wɝ ɹipleɪs baɪ stʃɹeɪt. ðə staɪflɪŋ hit dɪmɪnɪʃt. ɹɑɾɪŋ foʊlɪdʒ ɡeɪv weɪ tə ðə mɪɹli dɪzizd. ən ðən nɑt dɪzizd, hi ɹilaɪzd. ðə fɔɹəst ɝaʊn əm bɪkeɪm ɹɛd wɪð nu ɡɹoʊθ, θɪk ɑn ðə bɹæntʃəz. bʌdz spɹaʊɾəd ɑn ði ʌndɝɡɹoʊθ, kɹipɝz kʌvɝd ðə ɹɑks wɪð ɡɹin, ən nu waɪldflaʊɹz dɑɾəd ðə ɡɹæs əz θɪk ən bɹaɪɾ əz wɛɹ ðə ɡɹin mæn wɔkt. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf spɹɪŋ, soʊ lɔŋ hɛl bæk baɪ wɪntɝ, naʊ ɹeɪs tə kætʃ ʌp tə wɛɹ ɪt ʃəd bi.

But the next morning, still nothing changed that Rand could see. The Blight faded as they rode south, of course. Twisted trees were replaced by straight. The stifling heat diminished. Rotting foliage gave way to the merely diseased. And then not diseased, he realized. The forest around them became red with new growth, thick on the branches. Buds sprouted on the undergrowth, creepers covered the rocks with green, and new wildflowers dotted the grass as thick and bright as where the Green Man walked. It was as if spring, so long held back by winter, now raced to catch up to where it should be.

hi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn u stɛɹd. "ə maɪɾi bloʊ," mɔɪɹeɪn mɝmɝd, ən wəd seɪ noʊ mɔɹ.

He was not the only one who stared. "A mighty blow," Moiraine murmured, and would say no more.

klaɪmɪŋ waɪldʒɹoʊz ɛntwaɪn ðə stoʊn kɑləm mɑɹkɪŋ ðə bɔɹɾɝ. mɛn keɪm aʊɾ ə ðə wɑtʃtaʊɝz tə ɡɹit ðɛm. ðəɹ wɑz ə stʌn kwɑləɾi tə ðɛɹ læftɝ, ən ðɛɹ aɪz ʃoʊn wɪð əmeɪz, əz ɪf ðeɪ kəd nɑt bɪliv ðə nu ɡɹæs ʌndɝ ðɛɹ stil-klæd fit.

Climbing wildrose entwined the stone column marking the Border. Men came out of the watchtowers to greet them. There was a stunned quality to their laughter, and their eyes shone with amaze, as if they could not believe the new grass under their steel-clad feet.

"ðə laɪɾ əz kɑŋkɝd ðə ʃædoʊ!"

"The Light has conquered the Shadow!"

"ə ɡɹeɪt vɪktɝi ɪn tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp! wɪv hæd ðə mɛsədʒ! vɪktɝi!"

"A great victory in Tarwin's Gap! We have had the message! Victory!"

"ðə laɪt blɛsɪz əs əɡɛn!"

"The Light blesses us again!"

"kɪŋ isɑɹ ɪz stʃɹɔŋ ɪn ðə laɪt," læn ɹɪplaɪd tə ɔl ðɛɹ ʃaʊts.

"King Easar is strong in the Light," Lan replied to all their shouts.

ðə wɑtʃmən wɑntəd tə tɛn mɔɪɹeɪn, əɹ ət list sɛn ən ɛskɔɹt wɪð ðɛm, bʌt ʃi ɹəfjuzd ɪɾ ɔl. ivən flæɾ ɑn əɹ bæk ɑn ə lɪɾɝ, ði ɛɛs sədaɪz pɹɛzəns wɑz sətʃ ðət ði ɑɹmɝd mɛn fɛl bæk, boʊɪŋ ən æksiɾɪŋ tə hɝ wɪʃɪz. ðɛɹ læftɝ fɑloʊɾ əz ɹænd ən ði ʌðɝz ɹoʊɾ ɑn.

The watchmen wanted to tend Moiraine, or at least send an escort with them, but she refused it all. Even flat on her back on a litter, the Aes Sedai's presence was such that the armored men fell back, bowing and acceding to her wishes. Their laughter followed as Rand and the others rode on.

ɪn ðə leɪɾ æftɝnun ðeɪ ɹitʃt fæl dæɹə, tə faɪn ðə ɡɹɪm-wɔl sɪɾi ɹɪŋɪŋ wɪð sɛləbɹeɪʃən. ɹɪŋɪŋ ɪn tʃɹuθ. ɹænd daʊɾɪd ɪf ðəɹ kəd bi ə bɛl ɪn ðə sɪɾi nɑt klæŋɪŋ, fɹəm ðə taɪniəst sɪlvɝ hɑɹnəs tʃaɪm tə ɡɹeɪt bɹɑnz ɡɔŋz ɪn ðɛɹ taʊɝ tɑps. ðə ɡeɪts stʊd waɪɾ oʊpən, ən mɛn ɹæn læfɪŋ ən sɪŋɪŋ ɪn ðə stʃɹits, flaʊɝz stʌk ɪn ðɛɹ tɑpnɑts ən ðə kɹɛvəsɪz ə ðɛɹ ɑɹmɝ. ðə kɑmən pipəl ə ðə taʊn hæd nɑt jɛt ɹɪtɝn fɹəm fæl mɝæn, bʌt ðə soʊlʒɝz wɝ nuli kʌm fɹəm tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp, ən ðɛɹ dʒɔɪ wɑz ɪnʌf tə fɪl ðə stʃɹits.

In the late afternoon they reached Fal Dara, to find the grim-walled city ringing with celebration. Ringing in truth. Rand doubted if there could be a bell in the city not clanging, from the tiniest silver harness chime to great bronze gongs in their tower tops. The gates stood wide open, and men ran laughing and singing in the streets, flowers stuck in their topknots and the crevices of their armor. The common people of the town had not yet returned from Fal Moran, but the soldiers were newly come from Tarwin's Gap, and their joy was enough to fill the streets.

"vɪktɝi ɪn ðə ɡæp! wi wʌn!"

"Victory in the Gap! We won!"

"ə mɪɹəkəl ɪn ðə ɡæp! ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz əz kʌm bæk!"

"A miracle in the Gap! The Age of Legends has come back!"

"spɹɪŋ!" ə ɡɹɪzəld oʊl soʊlʒɝ læft əz i hʌŋ ə ɡɑɹlən ə mɔɹnɪŋstɑɹz ɝaʊn ɹændz nɛk. hɪz oʊn tɑpnɑt wɑz ə waɪt klʌstɝ ə ðɛm. "ðə laɪt blɛsɪz əs wɪð spɹɪŋ wʌns mɔɹ!"

"Spring!" a grizzled old soldier laughed as he hung a garland of morningstars around Rand's neck. His own topknot was a white cluster of them. "The Light blesses us with spring once more!"

lɝnɪŋ ðeɪ wɑntəd tə ɡoʊ tə ðə kip, ə sɝkəl ə mɛn klæɾ ɪn stil ən flaʊɝz sɝaʊndəd ðɛm, ɹʌnɪŋ tə klɪɹ ə weɪ θɹu ðə sɛləbɹeɪʃən.

Learning they wanted to go to the keep, a circle of men clad in steel and flowers surrounded them, running to clear a way through the celebration.

ɪŋtʃɹz wɑz ðə fɝs feɪs ɹænd sɔ ðət wɑz nɑt smaɪlɪŋ. "aɪ wɑz tu leɪt," ɪŋtʃɹ toʊld læn wɪð ə saʊɝ ɡɹɪmnəs. "tu leɪt baɪ ən aʊɝ tə si. pis!" hɪz tiθ ɡɹaʊn ɑɾəbli, bʌt ðən ɪz ɪkspɹɛʃən bɪkeɪm kəntʃɹaɪt. "fɝɡɪv mi. ɡɹif meɪks mi fɝɡɛt maɪ duɾiz. wɛlkəm, bɪldɝ. wɛlkəm tə jə ɔl. ɪts ɡʊd tə si jə seɪfli aʊɾ ə ðə blaɪt. əl bɹɪŋ ðə hilɝ tə mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ ɪn əɹ tʃeɪmbɝz, ən ɪnfɔɹm lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ - "

Ingtar's was the first face Rand saw that was not smiling. "I was too late," Ingtar told Lan with a sour grimness. "Too late by an hour to see. Peace!" His teeth ground audibly, but then his expression became contrite. "Forgive me. Grief makes me forget my duties. Welcome, Builder. Welcome to you all. It is good to see you safely out of the Blight. I will bring the healer to Moiraine Sedai in her chambers, and inform Lord Agelmar - "

"teɪk mi tə lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn kəmændəd. "teɪk əs ɔl." ɪŋtʃɹ oʊpən ɪz maʊθ tə pɹoʊtɛst, ən baʊɾ ʌndɝ ðə fɔɹs ə hɝ aɪz.

"Take me to Lord Agelmar," Moiraine commanded. "Take us all." Ingtar opened his mouth to protest, and bowed under the force of her eyes.

eɪɡəlmɝ wɑz ɪn ɪz stʌɾi, wɪð ɪz sɔɹdz ən ɑɹmɝ bæk ɑn ðɛɹ ɹæks, ən ɪz wɑz ðə sɛkən feɪs ðət dɪd nɑt smaɪl. hi wɔɹ ə tʃɹʌbəl fɹaʊn ðət dipənd wən i sɔ mɔɪɹeɪn kæɹiɾ ɪn ɑn əɹ lɪɾɝ baɪ lɪvɹid sɝvəns. wɪmən ɪn ðə blæk-ænd-ɡoʊl flʌɾɝd oʊvɝ bɹɪŋɪŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hɪm wɪθaʊɾ ə tʃæns tə fɹɛʃən hɝsɛlf əɹ bi bɹɔt ðə hilɝ. lɔɪəl kæɹid ðə ɡoʊl tʃɛst. ðə pisəz ə ðə sil wɝ stɪl ɪn mɔɪɹeɪnz paʊtʃ; luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝz bænɝ wɑz ɹæpt ɪn əɹ blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl ən stɪl taɪd bɪhaɪn ɑldibz sæɾəl. ðə ɡɹum u hæd lɛd ðə waɪt mɛɹ əweɪ hæd ɹəsiv ðə stʃɹɪktəst ɔɹɾɝz tə si ðə blæŋkɪtʃɹoʊl wɑz pleɪst əntʌtʃt ɪn ðə tʃeɪmbɝz əsaɪn tə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Agelmar was in his study, with his swords and armor back on their racks, and his was the second face that did not smile. He wore a troubled frown that deepened when he saw Moiraine carried in on her litter by liveried servants. Women in the black-and-gold fluttered over bringing the Aes Sedai to him without a chance to freshen herself or be brought the healer. Loial carried the gold chest. The pieces of the seal were still in Moiraine's pouch; Lews Therin Kinslayer's banner was wrapped in her blanketroll and still tied behind Aldieb's saddle. The groom who had led the white mare away had received the strictest orders to see the blanketroll was placed untouched in the chambers assigned to the Aes Sedai.

"pis!" ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə mʌɾɝd. "ɑɹ jə ɪnʒɝd, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ? ɪŋtʃɹ, waɪ hæv jə nɑt sin ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hɝ bɛɾ ən bɹɔt ðə hilɝ tə hɝ?"

"Peace!" the Lord of Fal Dara muttered. "Are you injured, Moiraine Sedai? Ingtar, why have you not seen the Aes Sedai to her bed and brought the healer to her?"

"bi stɪl, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "ɪŋtʃɹ əz dʌn əz aɪ kəmændəd hɪm. aɪm nɑt soʊ fɹeɪl əz ɛvɹiwʌn hɪɹ simz tə θɪŋk." ʃi moʊʃən tu ʌv ðə wɪmən tə hɛlp əɹ tə ə tʃɛɹ. fəɹ ə moʊmən ðeɪ klæsp ðɛɹ hænz, ɪkskleɪmɪŋ ðət ʃi wɑz tu wik, ðət ʃi ʃəd bi ɪn ə wɔɹm bɛd, ən ðə hilɝ bɹɔt, ən ə hɑt bæθ. mɔɪɹeɪnz aɪbɹaʊz lɪftəd; ðə wɪmən ʃʌt ðɛɹ maʊðz əbɹʌpli ən hɝid tə eɪɾ əɹ ɪndə ðə tʃɛɹ. əz sun əz ʃi wɑz sɛɾəld ʃi weɪvd əm əweɪ ɪɹɪɾəbli. "aɪ wəd spik wɪð ju, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ."

"Be still, Lord Agelmar," Moiraine said. "Ingtar has done as I commanded him. I am not so frail as everyone here seems to think." She motioned two of the women to help her to a chair. For a moment they clasped their hands, exclaiming that she was too weak, that she should be in a warm bed, and the healer brought, and a hot bath. Moiraine's eyebrows lifted; the women shut their mouths abruptly and hurried to aid her into the chair. As soon as she was settled she waved them away irritably. "I would speak with you, Lord Agelmar."

eɪɡəlmɝ nɑɾəd, ən ɪŋtʃɹ weɪv ðə sɝvəns fɹəm ðə ɹum. ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə aɪd ðoʊz u ɹɪmeɪn ɪkspɛktənli; ɪspɛʃli, ɹænd θɔt, lɔɪəl ən ðə ɡoʊldən tʃɛst.

Agelmar nodded, and Ingtar waved the servants from the room. The Lord of Fal Dara eyed those who remained expectantly; especially, Rand thought, Loial and the golden chest.

"wi hɪɹ," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛɾ əz sun əz ðə dɔɹ ʃʌt bɪhaɪn ɪŋtʃɹ, "ðæt jə wʌn ə ɡɹeɪt vɪktɝi ɪn tɑɹwɪnz ɡæp."

"We hear," Moiraine said as soon as the door shut behind Ingtar, "that you won a great victory in Tarwin's Gap."

"jɛs," eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd sloʊli, hɪz tʃɹʌbəl fɹaʊn ɹɪtɝnɪŋ. "jɛs, ɛɛs sədaɪ, ən noʊ. ðə hæfmən ən ðɛɹ tʃɹɑləks wɝ dɪstʃɹɔɪd tə ðə læst, bʌt wi bɛɹli fɔt. ə mɪɹəkəl, maɪ mɛn kɔl ɪt. ði ɝθ swɑloʊd ðɛm; ðə maʊntənz bɛɹid ðɛm. oʊnli ə fju dʒɹæɡkɝ wɝ lɛft, tu fɹaɪɾənd tə də ɛls bʌt flaɪ nɔɹθ əz fæst əz ðeɪ kʊd."

"Yes," Agelmar said slowly, his troubled frown returning. "Yes, Aes Sedai, and no. The Halfmen and their Trollocs were destroyed to the last, but we barely fought. A miracle, my men call it. The earth swallowed them; the mountains buried them. Only a few Draghkar were left, too frightened to do else but fly north as fast as they could."

"ə mɪɹəkəl ɪndid," mɔɪɹeɪn sɛd. "æn spɹɪŋ əz kʌm əɡɛn."

"A miracle indeed," Moiraine said. "And spring has come again."

"ə mɪɹəkəl," eɪɡəlmɝ sɛd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛd, "bʌt. . . . mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ, mɛn seɪ mɛni θɪŋz əbaʊt wʌt hæpən ɪn ðə ɡæp. ðət ðə laɪt tʊk ɑn flɛʃ ən fɔt fəɹ ʌs. ðət ðə kɹieɪɾɝ wɔkt ɪn ðə ɡæp tə stʃɹaɪk ət ðə ʃædoʊ. bʌɾ aɪ sɔ ə mæn, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ. aɪ sɔ ə mæn, ən wʌɾ i dɪd, kænɑt bi, mʌs nɑt bi."

"A miracle," Agelmar said, shaking his head, "but. . . . Moiraine Sedai, men say many things about what happened in the Gap. That the Light took on flesh and fought for us. That the Creator walked in the Gap to strike at the Shadow. But I saw a man, Moiraine Sedai. I saw a man, and what he did, cannot be, must not be."

"ðə wil wivz əz ðə wil wɪlz, lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə."

"The Wheel weaves as the Wheel wills, Lord of Fal Dara."

"æz jə seɪ, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ."

"As you say, Moiraine Sedai."

"æn pdən feɪn? hiz sɪkjʊɹ? aɪ mʌst spik wɪð ɪm wən aɪm ɹɛstəd."

"And Padan Fain? He is secure? I must speak with him when I am rested."

"hi ɪz hɛld əz jə kəmændəd, ɛɛs sədaɪ, waɪnɪŋ əɾ ɪz ɡɑɹdz hæf ðə taɪm ən tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə kəmæn əm ðə ɹɛst, bʌt. . . . pis, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ, wʌɾ ə ju, ɪn ðə blaɪt? jə faʊn ðə ɡɹin mæn? aɪ si hɪz hæn ɪn ðə nu θɪŋz ɡɹoʊɪŋ."

"He is held as you commanded, Aes Sedai, whining at his guards half the time and trying to command them the rest, but. . . . Peace, Moiraine Sedai, what of you, in the Blight? You found the Green Man? I see his hand in the new things growing."

"wi faʊn hɪm," ʃi sɛd flætli. "ðə ɡɹin mæn ɪz dɛd, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ, ən ði aɪ ʌv ðə wɝld ɪz ɡɔn. ðəɹ wɪl bi noʊ mɔɹ kwɛsts baɪ jʌŋ mɛn sikɪŋ ɡlɔɹi."

"We found him," she said flatly. "The Green Man is dead, Lord Agelmar, and the Eye of the World is gone. There will be no more quests by young men seeking glory."

ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə fɹaʊnd, ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪz hɛɾ ɪn kənfjuʒən. "dɛd? ðə ɡɹin mæn? hi kænɑt bi. . . . ðən jə wɝ dɪfiɾəd? bʌt ðə flaʊɝz, ən ðə ɡɹoʊɪŋ θɪŋz?"

The Lord of Fal Dara frowned, shaking his head in confusion. "Dead? The Green Man? He cannot be. . . . Then you were defeated? But the flowers, and the growing things?"

"wi wʌn, lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ. wi wʌn, ən ðə læn fɹid fɹəm wɪntɝ ɪz ðə pɹuf, bʌɾ aɪ fɪɹ ðə læs bæɾəl əz nɑt jɛt bɪn fɔt." ɹænd stɝd, bʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪv ɪm ə ʃɑɹp lʊk ən i stʊd stɪl əɡɛn. "ðə blaɪt stɪl stænz, ən ðə fɔɹdʒɪz ə θɑkændɑɹ stɪl wɝk bɪloʊ ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl. ðəɹ ɑɹ mɛni hæfmən jɛt, ən kaʊnləs tʃɹɑləks. nɛvɝ θɪŋk ðə nid fəɹ wɑtʃfəlnəs ɪn ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz ɪz ɡɔn."

"We won, Lord Agelmar. We won, and the land freed from winter is the proof, but I fear the last battle has not yet been fought." Rand stirred, but the Aes Sedai gave him a sharp look and he stood still again. "The Blight still stands, and the forges of Thakan'dar still work below Shayol Ghul. There are many Halfmen yet, and countless Trollocs. Never think the need for watchfulness in the Borderlands is gone."

"aɪ dɪd nɑt θɪŋk ɪt soʊ, ɛɛs sədaɪ," hi sɛd stɪfli.

"I did not think it so, Aes Sedai," he said stiffly.

mɔɪɹeɪn moʊʃən fəɹ lɔɪəl tə sɛt ðə ɡoʊl tʃɛst əɾ əɹ fit, ən wən i dɪd, ʃi oʊpən ɪt, ɹɪvilɪŋ ðə hɔɹn. "ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ," ʃi sɛd, ən eɪɡəlmɝ ɡæspt. ɹænd ɔlmoʊs θɔt ðə mæn wəd nil.

Moiraine motioned for Loial to set the gold chest at her feet, and when he did, she opened it, revealing the horn. "The Horn of Valere," she said, and Agelmar gasped. Rand almost thought the man would kneel.

"wɪð ðæt, mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ, ɪt mæɾɝz nɑt haʊ mɛni hæfmən əɹ tʃɹɑləks ɹɪmeɪn. wɪð ðə hɪɹoʊz ʌv oʊl kʌm bæk fɹəm ðə tum, wɪl mɑɹtʃ tə ðə blæstəd lænz ən lɛvəl ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl."

"With that, Moiraine Sedai, it matters not how many Halfmen or Trollocs remain. With the heroes of old come back from the tomb, we will march to the Blasted Lands and level Shayol Ghul."

"noʊ!" eɪɡəlmɝz maʊθ fɛl oʊpən ɪn sɝpɹaɪz, bʌt mɔɪɹeɪn kəntɪnjud kɑmli. "aɪ dɪd nɑt ʃoʊ ɪt tə jə tə tɔn ju, bʌt soʊ ðət jəl noʊ ðəɾ ɪn wʌtɛvɝ bæɾəlz jɛt kʌm, əɹ maɪt wɪl bi əz ɡɹeɪɾ əz ðəɾ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. ɪts pleɪs ɪz nɑt hɪɹ. ðə hɔɹn mʌs bi kæɹid tə ɪljən. ɪts ðɛɹ, ɪf fɹɛʃ bæɾəlz θɹɛɾən, ðəɾ ɪt mʌst ɹæli ðə fɔɹsɪz ə ðə laɪt. əl æsk ən ɛskɔɹɾ ə jəɹ bɛs mɛn tə si ðəɾ ɪt ɹitʃəz ɪljən seɪfli. ðəɹ ɑɹ dɑɹkfɹɛnz stɪl, əz wɛl əz hæfmən ən tʃɹɑləks, ən ðoʊz u kʌm tə ðə hɔɹn wɪl fɑloʊ huɛvɝ wɪnz ɪt. ɪt mʌst ɹitʃ ɪljən."

"NO!" Agelmar's mouth fell open in surprise, but Moiraine continued calmly. "I did not show it to you to taunt you, but so that you will know that in Whatever battles yet come, our might will be as great as that of the Shadow. Its place is not here. The Horn must be carried to Illian. It is there, if fresh battles threaten, that it must rally the forces of the Light. I will ask an escort of your best men to see that it reaches Illian safely. There are Darkfriends still, as well as Halfmen and Trollocs, and those who come to the horn will follow whoever winds it. It must reach Illian."

"ɪt ʃæl bi əz jə seɪ, ɛɛs sədaɪ." bʌt wən ðə lɪɾ ə ðə tʃɛs kloʊzd, ðə lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə lʊk laɪk ə mæn biɪŋ dɪnaɪɾ ɪz læst ɡlɪmps ə ðə laɪt.

"It shall be as you say, Aes Sedai." But when the lid of the chest closed, the Lord of Fal Dara looked like a man being denied his last glimpse of the Light.

sɛvən deɪz leɪɾɝ, bɛlz stɪl ɹæŋ ɪn fæl dæɹə. ðə pipəl hæd ɹɪtɝn fɹəm fæl mɝæn, æɾɪŋ ðɛɹ sɛləbɹeɪʃən tə ðəɾ ə ðə soʊlʒɝz, ən ʃaʊts ən sɪŋɪŋ blɛndəd wɪð ðə pilɪŋ ə ðə bɛlz ɑn ðə lɔŋ bælkəni wɛɹ ɹænd stʊd. ðə bælkəni oʊvɝlʊkt eɪɡəlmɝz pɹaɪvət ɡɑɹɾənz, ɡɹin ən flaʊɝɪŋ, bʌɾ i dɪd nɑt ɡɪv əm ə sɛkən lʊk. dɪspaɪt ðə sʌn haɪ ɪn ðə skaɪ, spɹɪŋ ɪn ʃaɪnɝ wɑz kulɝ ðən i wɑz juz tə, jɛt swɛt ɡlɪsən ɑn ɪz bɛɹ tʃɛst ən ʃoʊldɝz əz i swʌŋ ðə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd, itʃ muv pɹɪsaɪs jɛt dɪstən fɹəm wɛɹ i floʊɾəd ɪn ðə vɔɪd. ivən ðɛɹ, hi wʌndɝd haʊ mʌtʃ dʒɔɪ ðəɹ wəd bi ɪn ðə taʊn ɪf ðeɪ nu ʌv ðə bænɝ mɔɪɹeɪn stɪl kɛp hɪɾən.

Seven days later, bells still rang in Fal Dara. The people had returned from Fal Moran, adding their celebration to that of the soldiers, and shouts and singing blended with the pealing of the bells on the long balcony where Rand stood. The balcony overlooked Agelmar's private gardens, green and flowering, but he did not give them a second look. Despite the sun high in the sky, spring in Shienar was cooler than he was used to, yet sweat glistened on his bare chest and shoulders as he swung the heron-mark blade, each move precise yet distant from where he floated in the void. Even there, he wondered how much joy there would be in the town if they knew of the banner Moiraine still kept hidden.

"ɡʊd, ʃifɝɾɝ." linɪŋ əɡɛns ðə ɹeɪlɪŋ wɪð ɪz ɑɹmz foʊldəɾ əkɹɔs ɪz tʃɛst, ðə wɔɹɾɝ wɑtʃt ɪm kɹɪɾɪkəli. "ju ɑɹ duɪŋ wɛl, bʌt doʊn pʊʃ soʊ hɑɹd. jə kæn bɪkʌm ə bleɪdmæstɝ ɪn ə fju wiks."

"Good, sheepherder." Leaning against the railing with his arms folded across his chest, the Warder watched him critically. "You are doing well, but don't push so hard. You can't become a blademaster in a few weeks."

ðə vɔɪd vænɪʃt laɪk ə pɹɪk bʌbəl. "aɪ doʊn kɛɹ əbaʊt biɪŋ ə bleɪdmæstɝ."

The void vanished like a pricked bubble. "I don't care about being a blademaster."

"ɪts ə bleɪdmæstɝz bleɪd, ʃifɝɾɝ."

"It's a blademaster's blade, sheepherder."

"aɪ dʒʌst wɑn maɪ fɑðɝ tə bi pɹaʊɾ ə mi." hɪz hæn taɪɾənd ɑn ðə ɹʌf lɛðɝ ə ðə hɪlt. aɪ dʒʌst wɑn tæm tə bi maɪ fɑðɝ. hi slæm ðə sɔɹɾ ɪndə ɪts skæbɝd. "ɛniweɪ, aɪ doʊn əv ə fju wiks."

"I just want my father to be proud of me." His hand tightened on the rough leather of the hilt. I just want Tam to be my father. He slammed the sword into its scabbard. "Anyway, I don't have a few weeks."

"ðɛn juv nɑt tʃeɪnʒd jəɹ maɪnd?"

"Then you've not changed your mind?"

"wʊd ju?" lænz ɪkspɹɛʃən hæd nɑɾ ɔltɝd; ðə flæt pleɪnz ə hɪz feɪs lʊkt əz ɪf ðeɪ kəd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ. "ju woʊn tʃɹaɪ tə stɑp mi? əɹ mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ?"

"Would you?" Lan's expression had not altered; the flat planes of his face looked as if they could not change. "You won't try to stop me? Or Moiraine Sedai?"

"ju kən də əz jə wɪl, ʃifɝɾɝ, əɹ əz ðə pæɾɝn wivz fəɹ ju." ðə wɔɹɾɝ stʃɹeɪɾənd. "aɪl liv jə naʊ."

"You can do as you will, sheepherder, or as the Pattern weaves for you." The Warder straightened. "I'll leave you now."

ɹænd tɝn tə wɑtʃ læn ɡoʊ, ən faʊn ɛɡwin stændɪŋ ðɛɹ.

Rand turned to watch Lan go, and found Egwene standing there.

"tʃeɪnʒd jəɹ maɪn əbaʊt wʌt, ɹænd?"

"Changed your mind about what, Rand?"

hi snætʃt ʌp ɪz ʃɝɾ ən koʊt, sʌɾənli filɪŋ ðə kul. "aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ əweɪ, ɛɡwin."

He snatched up his shirt and coat, suddenly feeling the cool. "I'm going away, Egwene."

"wɛɹ?"

"Where?"

"sʌmwɛɹ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ." hi dɪd nɑt wɑnə miɾ əɹ aɪz, bʌɾ i kəd nɑt stɑp lʊkɪŋ ət hɝ. ʃi wɔɹ fɛd waɪld-ɹoʊzɪz twaɪn ɪn əɹ hɛɹ, floʊɪŋ əbaʊɾ əɹ ʃoʊldɝz. ʃi hɛld əɹ kloʊk kloʊs, dɑɹk blu ən ɛmbɹɔɪɾɝd əlɔŋ ði ɛdʒ wɪð ə θɪn laɪn ʌv waɪt flaʊɝz ɪn ðə ʃaɪnɝən fæʃən, ən ðə blɑsəmz meɪɾ ə laɪn stʃɹeɪɾ ʌp tə hɝ feɪs. ðeɪ wɝ noʊ pəlɝ ðən əɹ tʃiks; hɝ aɪz sim soʊ lɑɹdʒ ən dɑɹk. "əweɪ."

"Somewhere. I don't know." He did not want to meet her eyes, but he could not stop looking at her. She wore fed wild-roses twined in her hair, flowing about her shoulders. She held her cloak close, dark blue and embroidered along the edge with a thin line of white flowers in the Shienaran fashion, and the blossoms made a line straight up to her face. They were no paler than her cheeks; her eyes seemed so large and dark. "Away."

"aɪm ʃʊɹ mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ wɪl nɑt laɪk jə dʒʌst ɡoʊɪŋ ɔf. æftɝ . . . æftɝ wʌt juv dʌn, jə dɪzɝv səm ɹɪwɔɹd."

"I'm sure Moiraine Sedai will not like you just going off. After . . . after what you've done, you deserve some reward."

"mɔɪɹeɪn dʌz nɑt noʊ aɪm əlaɪv. aɪ hæv dʌn wʌt ʃi wɑntəd, ən ðæts ən ɛn tə ɪt. ʃi dʌzn ivən spik tə mi wən aɪ ɡoʊ tə hɝ. nɑt ðəɾ aɪv tʃɹaɪd tə steɪ kloʊs tə hɝ, bʌt ʃiz əvɔɪɾəd mi. ʃi woʊn kɛɹ ɪf aɪ ɡoʊ, ən aɪ doʊn kɛɹ ɪf ʃi dʌz."

"Moiraine does not know I am alive. I have done what she wanted, and that's an end to it. She doesn't even speak to me when I go to her. Not that I've tried to stay close to her, but she's avoided me. She won't care if I go, and I don't care if she does."

"mɔɪɹeɪn ɪz stɪl nɑt kəmplitli wɛl, ɹænd." ʃi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. "aɪ hæv tə ɡoʊ tə tɑɹ vəlɑn fəɹ maɪ tʃɹeɪnɪŋ. nɪneɪiv ɪz kʌmɪŋ, tu. ən mæt stɪl nidz tə bi hild ʌv wʌtɛvɝ baɪnz ɪm tə ðət dæɡɝ, ən pɛɹɪn wɑns tə si tɑɹ vəlɑn bɪfɔɹ i ɡoʊz . . . wɛɹɛvɝ. jə kəd kʌm wɪð ʌs."

"Moiraine is still not completely well, Rand." She hesitated. "I have to go to Tar Valon for my training. Nynaeve is coming, too. And Mat still needs to be Healed of Whatever binds him to that dagger, and Perrin wants to see Tar Valon before he goes . . . wherever. You could come with us."

"ænd weɪt fəɹ səm ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪsaɪdz mɔɪɹeɪn tə faɪn aʊt wʌɾ aɪm ən dʒɛntəl mi?" hɪz vɔɪs wɑz ɹʌf, ɔlmoʊst ə snɪɹ; hi kəd nɑt tʃeɪnʒ ɪt. "ɪz ðət wʌt jə wɑnt?"

"And wait for some Aes Sedai besides Moiraine to find out what I am and gentle me?" His voice was rough, almost a sneer; he could not change it. "Is that what you want?"

"noʊ."

"No."

hi nu hi wəd nɛvɝ bi eɪbəl tə tɛl əɹ haʊ ɡɹeɪtfəl i wɑz ðət ʃi hæd nɑt hɛzɪteɪɾɪd bɪfɔɹ ænsɝɪŋ.

He knew he would never be able to tell her how grateful he was that she had not hesitated before answering.

"ɹænd, jə ɑɹən əfɹeɪd. . . ." ðeɪ wɝ əloʊn, bʌt ʃi lʊkt ɝaʊn ən stɪl loʊɝɾ əɹ vɔɪs. "mɔɪɹeɪn sədaɪ sɛz jə doʊn əv tə tʌtʃ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. ɪf jə doʊn tʌtʃ seɪɾɪn, ɪf jə doʊn tʃɹaɪ tə wil ðə paʊɝ, jəl bi seɪf."

"Rand, you aren't afraid. . . ." They were alone, but she looked around and still lowered her voice. "Moiraine Sedai says you don't have to touch the True Source. If you don't touch saidin, if you don't try to wield the Power, you'll be safe."

"oʊ, aɪ woʊn ɛvɝ tʌtʃ ɪɾ əɡɛn. nɑɾ ɪf aɪ hæv tə kʌt maɪ hæn ɔf, fɝst." wʌɾ ɪf aɪ kæn stɑp? aɪ nɛvɝ tʃɹaɪd tə wild ɪt, nɑɾ ivən ət ði aɪ. wʌɾ ɪf aɪ kæn stɑp?

"Oh, I won't ever touch it again. Not if I have to cut my hand off, first." What if I can't stop? I never tried to wield it, not even at the Eye. What if I can't stop?

"wɪl jə ɡoʊ hoʊm, ɹænd? jəɹ fɑðɝ mʌs bi daɪɪŋ tə si ju. ivən mæts fɑðɝ mʌs bi daɪɪŋ tə si hɪm baɪ naʊ. əl bi kʌmɪŋ bæk tə ɛmənz fil nɛks jɪɹ. fəɹ ə lɪɾəl waɪl, ət list."

"Will you go home, Rand? Your father must be dying to see you. Even Mat's father must be dying to see him by now. I'll be coming back to Emond's Field next year. For a little while, at least."

hi ɹʌbd ɪz pɑm oʊvɝ ðə hɪlt ə hɪz sɔɹd, filɪŋ ðə bɹɑnz hɛɹən. maɪ fɑðɝ. hoʊm. laɪt, haʊ aɪ wɑnə si. . . . "nɑt hoʊm." sʌmpleɪs wɛɹ ðəɹ ɑɹən ɛni pipəl tə hɝɾ ɪf aɪ kæn stɑp maɪsɛlf. sʌmwɛɹ əloʊn. sʌɾənli ɪt fɛlt əz koʊld əz snoʊ ɑn ðə bælkəni. "aɪm ɡoʊɪŋ əweɪ, bʌt nɑt hoʊm." ɛɡwin, ɛɡwin, waɪ dɪd juv tə bi wʌn ə ðoʊz . . . ? hi pʊɾ ɪz ɑɹmz ɝaʊn hɝ, ən wɪspɝɾ ɪndə hɝ hɛɹ. "nɑɾ ɛvɝ hoʊm."

He rubbed his palm over the hilt of his sword, feeling the bronze heron. My father. Home. Light, how I want to see. . . . "Not home." Someplace where there aren't any people to hurt if I can't stop myself. Somewhere alone. Suddenly it felt as cold as snow on the balcony. "I'm going away, but not home." Egwene, Egwene, why did you have to be one of those . . . ? He put his arms around her, and whispered into her hair. "Not ever home."

ɪn eɪɡəlmɝz pɹaɪvət ɡɑɹɾən, ʌndɝ ə θɪk baʊɝ dɑɾəd wɪð waɪt blɑsəmz, mɔɪɹeɪn ʃɪftəɾ ɑn əɹ bɛdtʃɛɹ. ðə fɹæɡməns ə ðə sil leɪ ɑn əɹ læp, ən ðə smɔl dʒɛm ʃi səmtaɪmz wɔɹ ɪn əɹ hɛɹ spʌn ən ɡlɪɾɝd ɑn ɪts ɡoʊl tʃeɪn fɹəm ði ɛnz ə hɝ fɪŋɡɝz. ðə feɪn blu ɡloʊ feɪɾəd fɹəm ðə stoʊn, ən ə smaɪl tʌtʃt əɹ lɪps. ɪt hæd noʊ paʊɝ ɪn ɪtsɛlf, ðə stoʊn, bʌt ðə fɝs juz ʃi hæɾ ɛvɝ lɝn ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, əz ə ɡɝl, ɪn ðə ɹɔɪəl pæləs ɪn kɛɹhin, wɑz juzɪŋ ðə stoʊn tə lɪsən tə pipəl wən ðeɪ θɔt ðeɪ wɝ tu fɑɹ ɔf tə bi oʊvɝhɝd.

In Agelmar's private garden, under a thick bower dotted with white blossoms, Moiraine shifted on her bedchair. The fragments of the seal lay on her lap, and the small gem she sometimes wore in her hair spun and glittered on its gold chain from the ends of her fingers. The faint blue glow faded from the stone, and a smile touched her lips. It had no power in itself, the stone, but the first use she had ever learned of the One Power, as a girl, in the Royal Palace in Cairhien, was using the stone to listen to people when they thought they were too far off to be overheard.

"ðə pɹɑfəsiz wɪl bi fʊlfɪld," ði ɛɛs sədaɪ wɪspɝd. "ðə dʒɹæɡən ɪz ɹibɔɹn."

"The Prophecies will be fulfilled," the Aes Sedai whispered. "The Dragon is Reborn."

ði ɛn ə ðə fɝs bʊk ə ðə wil ə taɪm ɡlɔsɝi eɪ noʊɾ ɑn deɪts ɪn ðɪs ɡlɔsɝi. ðə toʊmən kæləndɝ (dɪvaɪz baɪ toʊmə dɝ ɑməd) wɑz ədɑptəɾ əpɹɑksəmətli tu sɛntʃɝiz æftɝ ðə dɛθ ə ðə læs meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ ən ɹəkɔɹɾəd jɪɹz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld (æb). mɛni ɹɛkɝdz wɝ dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, soʊ mʌtʃ soʊ ðət wɪð ði ɛn ə ðə wɔɹz ðəɹ wɑz ɑɹɡjəmən əbaʊt ði ɪɡzæk jɪɹ ʌndɝ ði oʊl sɪstəm. ə nu kæləndɝ wɑz pɹəpoʊz baɪ tiəm ʌv ɡɑzɹ, sɛləbɹeɪɾɪŋ ðə səpoʊz fɹiɾəm fɹəm ðə tʃɹɑlɑk θɹɛɾ ən ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ itʃ jɪɹ əz ə fɹi jɪɹ (fi). ðə ɡɑzɝən kæləndɝ ɡeɪnd waɪɾ æksɛptəns wɪðɪn twɛnti jɪɹz æftɝ ðə wɔɹz' ɛnd. ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ətɛmptəd tə ɪstæblɪʃ ə nu kæləndɝ beɪst ɑn ðə faʊndɪŋ ə hɪz ɛmpaɪɝ (, fɹəm ðə faʊndɪŋ), bʌt ðɪs ɪz naʊ noʊn ən ɹəfɝd tə oʊnli baɪ hɪstɔɹiənz. æftɝ ðə waɪdspɹɛd dɪstʃɹʌkʃən, dɛθ ən dɪsɹʌpʃən ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, ə fɔɹθ kæləndɝ wɑz dɪvaɪz baɪ ɝɛn dɪn dʒubaɪ sɔɹɪŋ ɡʌl, ə skɑlɝ ə ðə si foʊk, ən pɹɑməlɡeɪɾəd baɪ ðə pɑnɑɹtʃ fɛɹiɾ ə tæɹɑbən. ðə fɛɹid kæləndɝ, deɪɾɪŋ fɹəm ði ɑɹbɪtʃɹɛɹəli dɪsaɪɾɪd ɛn ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz ən ɹəkɔɹɾɪŋ jɪɹz ə ðə nu ɛɹə (nəbɹæskə), ɪz kɝənli ɪn jus.

The End of the First Book of The Wheel of Time GLOSSARY A Note on Dates in This Glossary. The Toman Calendar (devised by Toma dur Ahmid) was adopted approximately two centuries after the death of the last male Aes Sedai and recorded years After the Breaking of the World (AB). Many records were destroyed in the Trolloc Wars, so much so that with the end of the Wars there was argument about the exact year under the old system. A new calendar was proposed by Tiam of Gazar, celebrating the supposed freedom from the Trolloc threat and recording each year as a Free Year (FY). The Gazaran Calendar gained wide acceptance within twenty years after the Wars' end. Artur Hawkwing attempted to establish a new calendar based on the founding of his empire (FF, From the Founding), but this is now known and referred to only by historians. After the widespread destruction, death and disruption of the War of the Hundred Years, a fourth calendar was devised by Uren din Jubai Soaring Gull, a scholar of the Sea Folk, and promulgated by the Panarch Farede of Tarabon. The Farede Calendar, dating from the arbitrarily decided end of the War of the Hundred Years and recording years of the New Era (NE), is currently in use.

eɪɾən, hɛɹən (eɪ-dæn, hɛ-ɹæn): ɡʌvɝnɝ ə bɛɹlən.

Adan, Heran (ay-DAN, HEH-ran): Governor of Baerlon.

ɛɛs sədaɪ (aɪɛz sɛ-dɪaɪ): wildɝz ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ. sɪns ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, ɔl sɝvaɪvɪŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ ɑɹ wɪmən. waɪdli dɪstʃɹʌstəɾ ən fɪɹd, ivən heɪɾəd, ðeɪ ɑɹ bleɪm baɪ mɛni fəɹ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ən ɑɹ dʒɛnɝəli θɔt tə mɛɾəl ɪn ði əfɛɹz ə neɪʃənz. ət ðə seɪm taɪm, fju ɹulɝz wɪl bi wɪθaʊɾ ən ɛɛs sədaɪ ædvaɪzɝ, ivən ɪn lænz wɛɹ ði ɛɡzɪstəns ə sətʃ ə kənɛkʃən mʌs bi kɛp sikɹət. juzd əz ən ɑnɝɪfɪk, soʊ: ʃɛɹiəm sədaɪ; ən əz ə haɪ ɑnɝɪfɪk, soʊ: ʃɛɹiəm ɛɛs sədaɪ. si ɔlsoʊ ədʒɑ; æmɪɝlɪn sit.

Aes Sedai (EYEZ seh-DEYE): Wielders of the One Power. Since the Time of Madness, all surviving Aes Sedai are women. Widely distrusted and feared, even hated, they are blamed by many for the Breaking of the World, and are generally thought to meddle in the affairs of nations. At the same time, few rulers will be without an Aes Sedai adviser, even in lands where the existence of such a connection must be kept secret. Used as an honorific, so: Sheriam Sedai; and as a high honorific, so: Sheriam Aes Sedai. See also Ajah; Amyrlin Seat.

eɪdʒ leɪs: si pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ.

Age Lace: See Pattern of an Age.

eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz: ði eɪdʒ ɛndəd baɪ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ ən ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ə taɪm wən ɛɛs sədaɪ pɝfɔɹmd wʌndɝz naʊ oʊnli dʒɹimd ʌv. si ɔlsoʊ wil ə taɪm.

Age of Legends: The Age ended by the War of the Shadow and the Breaking of the World. A time when Aes Sedai performed wonders now only dreamed of. See also Wheel of Time.

eɪɡəlmɝ; lɔɹɾ eɪɡəlmɝ ə haʊs ə dʒəɡəd (æɡ-ɛl-mɑɹ; dʒɑ-ɡæd): lɔɹɾ ə fæl dæɹə. hɪz saɪn ɪz θɹi ɹʌnɪŋ ɹɛd fɑksəz.

Agelmar; Lord Agelmar of House of Jagad (AGH-el-mar; JAH-gad): Lord of Fal Dara. His sign is three running red foxes.

il (aɪ-il): ðə pipəl ə ði il weɪst. fɪɹs ən hɑɹɾi. ɔlsoʊ kɔld ilmɛn. ðeɪ veɪl ðɛɹ feɪsəz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ kɪl, ɡɪvɪŋ ɹaɪz tə ðə seɪɪŋ "æktɪŋ laɪk ə blæk-veɪld il" tə dɪskɹaɪb sʌmwʌn u ɪz biɪŋ vaɪələnt. dɛdli wɔɹiɝz wɪð wɛpənz əɹ wɪð nʌθɪŋ bʌt ðɛɹ bɛɹ hænz, ðəl nɑt tʌtʃ ə sɔɹd. ðɛɹ paɪpɝz pleɪ ðɛm ɪndə bæɾəl wɪð ðə mjuzɪk ə dænsəz, ən ilmɛn kɔl bæɾəl "ðə dæns."

Aiel (eye-EEL): The people of the Aiel Waste. Fierce and hardy. Also called Aielmen. They veil their faces before they kill, giving rise to the saying "acting like a black-veiled Aiel" to describe someone who is being violent. Deadly warriors with weapons or with nothing but their bare hands, they will not touch a sword. Their pipers play them into battle with the music of dances, and Aielmen call battle "the Dance."

il weɪst: ðə hɑɹʃ, ɹʌɡəɾ ən ɔl-bʌt-wɔɾɝləs læn ist ə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld. fju aʊtsaɪɾɝz vɛntʃɝ ðɛɹ, nɑɾ oʊnli kəz wɔɾɝ ɪz ɔlmoʊst ɪmpɑsəbəl tə faɪn fəɹ wʌn nɑt bɔɹn ðɛɹ, bʌt kəz ði il kənsɪɾɝ ðɛmsɛlvz ət wɔɹ wɪð ɔl ʌðɝ pipəlz ən də nɑt wɛlkəm stʃɹeɪnʒɝz.

Aiel Waste: The harsh, rugged and all-but-waterless land east of the Spine of the World. Few outsiders venture there, not only because water is almost impossible to find for one not born there, but because the Aiel consider themselves at war with all other peoples and do not welcome strangers.

ədʒɑ (ɑ-dʒɑ): səsaɪəɾiz əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, tə wɪtʃ ɔl ɛɛs sədaɪ bɪlɔŋ. ðeɪ ɑɹ dɛzɪɡneɪɾɪd baɪ kʌlɝz: blu ədʒɑ, ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ, waɪɾ ədʒɑ, ɡɹin ədʒɑ, bɹaʊn ədʒɑ, jɛloʊ ədʒɑ, ən ɡɹeɪ ədʒɑ. itʃ fɑloʊz ə spəsɪfɪk fəlɑsəfi ʌv ðə jus ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ən pɝpəsəz ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ bɛnz ɔl ɪts ɛnɝdʒiz tə faɪndɪŋ ən dʒɛntəlɪŋ mɛn u ɑɹ ətɛmptɪŋ tə wil ðə paʊɝ. ðə bɹaʊn ədʒɑ, ɑn ði ʌðɝ hænd, fɔɹseɪks ɪnvɑlvmənt wɪð ðə wɝld ən dɛɾɪkeɪts ɪtsɛlf tə sikɪŋ nɑlədʒ. ðəɹ ɑɹ ɹumɝz (hɑtli dɪnaɪd, ən nɛvɝ seɪfli mɛnʃən ɪn fɹʌn ʌv ɛni ɛɛs sədaɪ) ʌv ə blæk ədʒɑ, dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə sɝvɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn.

Ajah (AH-jah): Societies among the Aes Sedai, to which all Aes Sedai belong. They are designated by colors: Blue Ajah, Red Ajah, White Ajah, Green Ajah, Brown Ajah, Yellow Ajah, and Gray Ajah. Each follows a specific philosophy of the use of the One Power and purposes of the Aes Sedai. For example, the Red Ajah bends all its energies to finding and gentling men who are attempting to wield the Power. The Brown Ajah, on the other hand, forsakes involvement with the world and dedicates itself to seeking knowledge. There are rumors (hotly denied, and never safely mentioned in front of any Aes Sedai) of a Black Ajah, dedicated to serving the Dark One.

æl ɛlɪsɑnd! (ɑlɛl-lɪ-sæn-dɑ): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "fɔɹ ðə ɹoʊz ə ðə sʌn!"

Al Ellisande! (ahlehl-lih-SAHN-dah): In the Old Tongue, "For the Rose of the Sun!"

ɑldib (ɑl-dib): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "wɛst waɪnd," ðə wɪn ðət bɹɪŋz ðə spɹɪŋ ɹeɪnz. ɑlmɹə, nɪneɪiv (ɑl-miɝ-ɑ, naɪ-niv): ðə wɪzdəm ʌv ɛmənz fild.

Aldieb (ahl-DEEB): In the Old Tongue, "West Wind," the wind that brings the spring rains. al'Meara, Nynaeve (ahl-MEER-ah, NIGH-neev): The Wisdom of Emond's Field.

ælθɹ, ɹænd (ɑl-θɔɹ, ɹænd): ə jʌŋ fɑɹmɝ ən ʃifɝɾɝ fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz.

al'Thor, Rand (ahl-THOR, RAND): A young farmer and sheepherder from the Two Rivers.

ælvɪɹ, ɛɡwin (ɑl-vɪɹ, ɛ-ɡweɪn): jʌŋɡəs dɔɾɝ ə ði ɪnkipɝ ɪn ɛmənz fild.

al'Vere, Egwene (ahl-VEER, eh-GWAIN): Youngest daughter of the innkeeper in Emond's Field.

æmɪɝlɪn sit (ɑm-ɛɹ-lɪn): (wʌn.) ðə taɪɾəl ə ðə liɾɝ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Amyrlin Seat (AHM-ehr-lin): (1.) The title of the leader of the Aes Sedai.

ɪlɛktəd fəɹ laɪf baɪ ðə hɔl ə ðə taʊɝ, ðə haɪəs kaʊnsəl ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ, wɪtʃ kənsɪsts ə θɹi ɹɛpɹəzɛntəɾɪvz fɹəm itʃ ə ðə sɛvən ədʒəz. ði æmɪɝlɪn sit hæz, θiɝɛɾɪkəli ət list, ɔlmoʊst səpɹim əθɔɹəɾi əmʌŋ ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ʃi ɹæŋks əz ði ikwəl ʌv ə kɪŋ əɹ kwin. (tu.) ðə θɹoʊn əpɑn wɪtʃ ðə liɾɝ ə ði ɛɛs sədaɪ sɪts.

Elected for life by the Hall of the Tower, the highest council of the Aes Sedai, which consists of three representatives from each of the seven Ajahs. The Amyrlin Seat has, theoretically at least, almost supreme authority among the Aes Sedai. She ranks as the equal of a king or queen. (2.) The throne upon which the leader of the Aes Sedai sits.

ændɝ ( æn-dɔɹ): ðə ɹɛlm wɪðɪn wɪtʃ ðə tu ɹɪvɝz laɪz. ðə saɪn ʌv ændɝ ɪz ə ɹæmpənt waɪt laɪən ɑn ə fild ə ɹɛd.

Andor ( AN-door): The realm within which the Two Rivers lies. The sign of Andor is a rampant white lion on a field of red.

æŋɡɹil (æn-ɡɹi-ɑl): ə vɛɹi ɹɛɹ ɑbʒɛkt wɪtʃ əlaʊz ɛniwʌn keɪpəbəl ə tʃænəlɪŋ ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə hændəl ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ əmaʊn ə ðə paʊɝ ðən wəd bi seɪfli pɑsəbəl əneɪɾɪd. ɹɛmnəns ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ðə minz ə ðɛɹ meɪkɪŋ ɪz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ noʊn. si ɔlsoʊ sɑŋɡɹil.

angreal (ahn-gree-AHL): A very rare object which allows anyone capable of channeling the One Power to handle a greater amount of the Power than would be safely possible unaided. Remnants of the Age of Legends, the means of their making is no longer known. See also sa'angreal.

ɝæfəl (ɑ-ɹɑ-fɛl): wʌn ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ðə saɪn ə ɝæfəl ɪz θɹi waɪt ɹoʊzɪz ɑn ə fild ə ɹɛd, kɔɹɾɝd wɪð θɹi ɹɛd ɹoʊzɪz ɑn ə fild ʌv waɪt.

Arafel (AH-rah-fehl): One of the Borderlands. The sign of Arafel is three white roses on a field of red, quartered with three red roses on a field of white.

ɛɹæm (eɪ-ɹæm): ə jʌŋ mæn ə ðə tuætɑn.

Aram (AY-ram): A young man of the Tuatha'an.

ɑvɛndɪsɔɹə (ɑ-vɛn-dɛ-soʊ-ɹɑ): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə tʃɹi ʌv laɪf." mɛnʃən ɪn mɛni stɔɹiz ən lɛdʒənz.

Avendesora (Ah-vehn-deh-SO-rah): In the Old Tongue, "the Tree of Life." Mentioned in many stories and legends.

eɪbɑɹə, pɛɹɪn (eɪ-bɛɹ-ɑ, pɛɹ-ɹɪn): ə jʌŋ blæksmɪθs əpɹɛntəs fɹəm ɛmənz fild.

Aybara, Perrin (ay-BAHR-ah, PEHR-rihn): A young blacksmith's apprentice from Emond's Field.

bælzəmən (bɑ-ɑl-zɑ-moʊn): ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk tʌŋ, "hɑɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk." bɪliv tə bi ðə tʃɹɑlɑk neɪm fəɹ ðə dɑɹk wʌn.

Ba'alzamon (bah-AHL-zah-mon): In the Trolloc tongue, "Heart of the Dark." Believed to be the Trolloc name for the Dark One.

bɛɹlən (beɪɹ-lɑn): ə sɪɾi ɪn ændɝ ɑn ðə ɹoʊd fɹəm keɪɛmlɪn tə ðə maɪnz ɪn ðə maʊntənz ə mɪst.

Baerlon (BAYR-lon): A city in Andor on the road from Caemlyn to the mines in the Mountains of Mist.

bæɹən, dɔɹæl (bɛɹ-ɹæn, dɔɹ-ɑl): ðə wɪzdəm ɪn ɛmənz fil pɹaɪɝ tə nɪneɪiv ɑlmɹə.

Barron, Doral (BAHR-rahn, DOOR-ahl): The Wisdom in Emond's Field prior to Nynaeve al'Meara.

bɛl taɪn (bɛl taɪn): spɹɪŋ fɛstəvəl ɪn ðə tu ɹɪvɝz.

Bel Tine (BEHL TINE): Spring festival in the Two Rivers.

baɪtim (baɪt-mi): ə smɔl, ɔlmoʊst ɪnvɪzəbəl baɪɾɪŋ ɪnsɛkt.

biteme (BITE-me): A small, almost invisible biting insect.

blæk ədʒɑsi ədʒɑ.

Black Ajah:See Ajah.

blæstəd lænz: dɛsəleɪɾɪd lænz sɝaʊndɪŋ ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, bɪɑn ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt.

Blasted Lands: Desolated lands surrounding Shayol Ghul, beyond the Great Blight.

blaɪt, ðəsi ɡɹeɪt blaɪt, ðə.

Blight, the:See Great Blight, the.

blu ədʒɑsi ədʒɑ.

Blue Ajah:See Ajah.

bɔɹɾɝlændz, ðə: ðə neɪʃənz bɔɹɾɝɪŋ ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt: sɑldɑiə, ɝæfəl, kændɝ, ən ʃaɪnɝ.

Borderlands, the: The nations bordering the Great Blight: Saldaea, Arafel, Kandor, and Shienar.

bɔɹnhəld, deɪn (-hɑld, deɪ-ɪn): ən ɔfəsɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt, sʌn ə lɔɹd kæptən dʒɛəfɹæm bɔɹnhəld.

Bornhald, Dain (BOHRN-hahld, DAY-ihn): An officer of the Children of the Light, son of Lord Captain Geofram Bornhald.

bɔɹnhəld, dʒɛəfɹæm (-hɑld, -ɹæm): eɪ lɔɹd kæptən ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Bornhald, Geofram (BOHRN-hahld, JEHF-rahm): A Lord Captain of the Children of the Light.

bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ðə: wən luz θɝɪn tɛləmən ən ðə hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz ɹisil ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən, ðə kaʊntɝstʃɹoʊk teɪntɪd seɪɾɪn. ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɛvɹi meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ wɛn hɔɹəbli ɪnseɪn. ɪn ðɛɹ mædnəs ðiz mɛn, hu kəd wil ðə wʌn paʊɝ tə ə dɪɡɹi naʊ ənnoʊn, tʃeɪnʒd ðə feɪs ə ði ɝθ. ðeɪ kɑzd ɡɹeɪɾ ɝθkweɪks, lɛvəl maʊntən ɹeɪnʒəz, ɹeɪz nu maʊntənz, lɪftəd dʒɹaɪ lænd wɛɹ siz hæd bɪn, meɪd ði oʊʃən ɹʌʃ ɪn wɛɹ dʒɹaɪ læn hæd bɪn. mɛni pɑɹts ə ðə wɝld wɝ kəmplitli dɪpɑpjəleɪɾɪd, ən ðə sɝvaɪvɝz wɝ skæɾɝd laɪk dʌst ɑn ðə wɪnd. ðɪs dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ɪz ɹɪmɛmbɝɾ ɪn stɔɹiz, lɛdʒənz ən hɪstɝi əz ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. si ɔlsoʊ hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz, ðə.

Breaking of the World, the: When Lews Therin Telamon and the Hundred Companions resealed the Dark One's prison, the counterstroke tainted saidin. Eventually every male Aes Sedai went horribly insane. In their madness these men, who could wield the One Power to a degree now unknown, changed the face of the earth. They caused great earthquakes, leveled mountain ranges, raised new mountains, lifted dry land where seas had been, made the ocean rush in where dry land had been. Many parts of the world were completely depopulated, and the survivors were scattered like dust on the wind. This destruction is remembered in stories, legends and history as the Breaking of the World. See also Hundred Companions, the.

bɹaɪn, ɡɛɹɪθ (bɹɪn, ɡɑ-ɹɛθ): kæptən-dʒɛnɝəl ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹɾ ɪn ændɝ. ɔlsoʊ sɝvz əz mɔɹɡeɪsəz fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd. hɪz saɪn ɪz θɹi ɡoʊldən stɑɹz, itʃ ə faɪv ɹeɪz.

Bryne, Gareth (BRIHN, GAH-rehth): Captain-General of the Queen's Guard in Andor. Also serves as Morgase's First Prince of the Sword. His sign is three golden stars, each of five rays.

baɪɑɝ, jɹət (baɪ-ɑɹ, dʒɑ-ɹɛt): ən ɔfəsɝ ə ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Byar, Jaret (BY-ahr, JAH-ret): An officer of the Children of the Light.

keɪɛmlɪn (keɪm-lɪn): ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ændɝ.

Caemlyn (KAYM-lihn): The capital city of Andor.

kɛɹhin (kaɪ-ɹi-ɛn): boʊθ ə neɪʃən əlɔŋ ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld ən ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ðət neɪʃən. ðə sɪɾi wɑz bɝn ən luɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ði il wɔɹ (naɪnsɛvənsɪksnaɪnsɛvəneɪt ni). ðə saɪn ə kɛɹhin ɪz ə mɛni-ɹeɪd ɡoʊldən sʌn ɹaɪzɪŋ fɹəm ðə bɑɾəm ʌv ə fild ə skaɪ blu.

Cairhien (KEYE-ree-EHN): Both a nation along the Spine of the World and the capital city of that nation. The city was burned and looted during the Aiel War (976978 NE). The sign of Cairhien is a many-rayed golden sun rising from the bottom of a field of sky blue.

kæɹɑi ən kɑldəzɑɹ! (kɑ-ɹeɪaɪ æn kɑl-dɑ-zɑɹ): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "fɔɹ ði ɑnɝ ə ðə ɹɛɾ iɡəl!" ði eɪntʃən bæɾəl kɹaɪ ʌv meɪnɛðɝən.

Carai an Caldazar! (cah-REYE ahn cahl-dah-ZAHR): In the Old Tongue, "For the honor of the Red Eagle!" The ancient battle cry of Manetheren.

kæɹɑi ən ɛlɪsɑnd!: ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "fɔɹ ði ɑnɝ ə ðə ɹoʊz ə ðə sʌn!" ðə bæɾəl kɹaɪ ʌv ðə læs kɪŋ ə meɪnɛðɝən.

Carai an Ellisande!: In the Old Tongue, "For the honor of the Rose of the Sun!" The battle cry of the last king of Manetheren.

kɔθən, meɪtʃɹim (mæt) (kɔ-θɑn, mæt-ɹɪm): ə jʌŋ fɑɹmɝ fɹəm ðə tu ɹɪvɝz.

Cauthon, Matrim (Mat) (CAW-thon, MAT-rihm): A young farmer from the Two Rivers.

tʃænəl: (wʌn) (vɝb) tə kəntʃɹoʊl ðə floʊ ʌv ðə wʌn paʊɝ. (tu) (naʊn) ði ækt ə kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ ðə floʊ ʌv ðə wʌn paʊɝ.

channel: (1) (verb) To control the flow of the One Power. (2) (noun) The act of controlling the flow of the One Power.

tʃɛɝɪn, dʒaɪn (tʃɑ-ɹɪn, dʒeɪ-ɪn): si fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ, dʒaɪn.

Charin, Jain (CHAH-rihn, JAY-ihn): See Farstrider, Jain.

tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt: ə səsaɪəɾi hoʊldɪŋ stʃɹɪkt əsɛɾɪk bɪlifs, dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə ðə dɪfiɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ʌv ɔl dɑɹkfɹɛnz. faʊndəd dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz baɪ lɑthɛɹ mæntəlɝ (loʊ-θheɪɹ mæn-ti-lɑɹ) tə pɹɑsələtaɪz əɡɛnst ɪnkɹisɪŋ nʌmbɝz ə dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ðeɪ ɪvɑlv dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ɪndə ə kəmplitli mɪlətɛɹi ɔɹɡənəzeɪʃən, ɪkstʃɹimli ɹɪdʒəɾ ɪn ðɛɹ bɪlifs ən kəmplitli sɝɾən ðəɾ oʊnli ðeɪ noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ən ðə ɹaɪt. ðeɪ heɪɾ ɛɛs sədaɪ, kənsɪɾɝɪŋ ðɛm, ən ɛni hu səpɔɹɾ əɹ bɪfɹɛn ðɛm, dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ðeɪ ɑɹ noʊn dɪspɛɹɪdʒɪŋli əz waɪtkloʊks; ðɛɹ saɪn ɪz ə ɡoʊldən sʌnbɝst ɑn ə fild ʌv waɪt.

Children of the Light: A society holding strict ascetic beliefs, dedicated to the defeat of the Dark One and the destruction of all Darkfriends. Founded during the War of the Hundred Years by Lothair Mantelar (LOH-thayr MAHN-tee-LAHR) to proselytize against increasing numbers of Darkfriends, they evolved during the war into a completely military organization, extremely rigid in their beliefs and completely certain that only they know the truth and the right. They hate Aes Sedai, considering them, and any who support or befriend them, Darkfriends. They are known disparagingly as Whitecloaks; their sign is a golden sunburst on a field of white.

kʌvənən ə ðə tɛn neɪʃənz: ə junjən fɔɹmd ɪn ðə sɛntʃɝiz æftɝ ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld (sɝkə tuhʌnʒɹəd æb). dɛɾəkeɪtəd tə ðə dɪfiɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn. bɹoʊkən əpɑɹt baɪ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz.

Covenant of the Ten Nations: A union formed in the centuries after the Breaking of the World (circa 200 AB). Dedicated to the defeat of the Dark One. Broken apart by the Trolloc Wars.

kwəndɪlɝ (kweɪn-dɛ-jɑɹ): si hɑɹtstoʊn.

cuendillar (CWAIN-deh-yar): See heartstone.

dəmədʒɹd, lɔɹd ɡɑleɪdɛdʒɹəd (dæm-oʊ-dʒɹɛd, ɡɑ-lɑd-ɛ-dʒɹaɪd): oʊnli sʌn ə tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl dəmədʒɹɾ ən tɪɡɹeɪn; hæf-bɹʌðɝ tə ɪleɪn ən ɡɔɪn. hɪz saɪn ɪz ə wɪŋ sɪlvɝ sɔɹd, pɔɪnt-daʊn.

Damodred, Lord Galadedrid (DAHM-oh-drehd, gah-LAHD-eh-drihd): Only son of Taringail Damodred and Tigraine; half-brother to Elayne and Gawyn. His sign is a winged silver sword, point-down.

dəmədʒɹd, pɹɪns tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl (dæm-oʊ-dʒɹɛd, tɑ-ɹɪn-ɡeɪl): eɪ ɹɔɪəl pɹɪns ə kɛɹhin, hi mɛɹid tɪɡɹeɪn ən fɑðɝd ɡɑleɪdɛdʒɹəd. wən tɪɡɹeɪn dɪsəpɪɹɾ ən wɑz dɪklɛɹd dɛd, hi mɛɹid mɔɹɡeɪs ən fɑðɝɾ ɪleɪn ən ɡɔɪn. hi daɪɾ ɪn ə hʌntɪŋ æksəɾənt. hɪz saɪn wɑz ə ɡoʊldən, dʌbəl-bɪɾɪd bæɾəl æks.

Damodred, Prince Taringail (DAHM-oh-drehd, TAH-rihn-gail): A Royal Prince of Cairhien, he married Tigraine and fathered Galadedrid. When Tigraine disappeared and was declared dead, he married Morgase and fathered Elayne and Gawyn. He died in a hunting accident. His sign was a golden, double-bitted battle axe.

dɑɹk wʌn: moʊs kɑmən neɪm, juzd ɪn ɛvɹi lænd, fəɹ ʃeɪtɑn: ðə sɔɹs ʌv ivəl, æntɪθəsəs ə ðə kɹieɪɾɝ. ɪmpɹɪzən baɪ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ət ðə moʊmən ə kɹieɪʃən ɪn ə pɹɪzən ət ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl; ən ətɛmp tə fɹi hɪm fɹəm ðət pɹɪzən bɹɔɾ əbaʊt ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ, ðə teɪntɪŋ ə seɪɾɪn, ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ən ði ɛn ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz.

Dark One: Most common name, used in every land, for Shai'tan: the source of evil, antithesis of the Creator. Imprisoned by the Creator at the moment of Creation in a prison at Shayol Ghul; an attempt to free him from that prison brought about the War of the Shadow, the tainting of saidin, the Breaking of the World, and the end of the Age of Legends.

dɑɹk wʌn, neɪmɪŋ ðə: seɪɪŋ ðə tʃɹu neɪm ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn (ʃeɪtɑn) dʒɹɔz ɪz ətɛnʃən, ɪnɛvəɾəbli bɹɪŋɪŋ ɪl fɔɹtʃən ət bɛst, dɪzæstɝ ət wɝst. fəɹ ðət ɹizən mɛni jufəmɪzəmz ɑɹ juzd, əmʌŋ əm ðə dɑɹk wʌn, fɑðɝ ə laɪz, saɪtblɪndɝ, lɔɹɾ ə ðə ɡɹeɪv, ʃɛpɝɾ ə ðə naɪt, hɑɹtsbeɪn, hɑɹtfæŋ, ɡɹæsbɝnɝ, ən lif blaɪɾɝ. sʌmwʌn u simz tə bi ɪnvaɪɾɪŋ ɪl fɔɹtʃən ɪz ɔfən sɛd tə bi "neɪmɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn."

Dark One, naming the: Saying the true name of the Dark One (Shai'tan) draws his attention, inevitably bringing ill fortune at best, disaster at worst. For that reason many euphemisms are used, among them the Dark One, Father of Lies, Sightblinder, Lord of the Grave, Shepherd of the Night, Heartsbane, Heartfang, Grassburner, and Leaf blighter. Someone who seems to be inviting ill fortune is often said to be "naming the Dark One."

dɑɹkfɹɛnz: ðoʊz u fɑloʊ ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən bɪliv ðəl ɡeɪn ɡɹeɪt paʊɝ ən ɹɪwɔɹdz wən hiz fɹid fɹəm ɪz pɹɪzən.

Darkfriends: Those who follow the Dark One and believe they will gain great power and rewards when he is freed from his prison.

dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ: taɪɾəl ə ði ɛɹ tə ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ. ði ɛldəs dɔɾɝ ə ðə kwin səksidz əɹ mʌðɝ ɑn ðə θɹoʊn. wɪθaʊɾ ə sɝvaɪvɪŋ dɔɾɝ, ðə θɹoʊn ɡoʊz tə ðə nɪɹəs fimeɪl blʌd-ɹileɪʃən ə ðə kwin.

Daughter-heir: Title of the heir to the throne of Andor. The eldest daughter of the Queen succeeds her mother on the throne. Without a surviving daughter, the throne goes to the nearest female blood-relation of the Queen.

dɑvɑl, deɪmən (dɑ-voʊl, dɪaɪ-moʊn): si tʃɹɑləks.

Dha'vol, Dhai'mon (DAH-vohl, DEYE-mon): See Trollocs.

jɛvɪk ɹ (jɛ-vɪk kɛ-ʃɑɹ): ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk tʌŋ, "ðə daɪɪŋ ɡɹaʊnd." ðə tʃɹɑlɑk neɪm fəɹ ði il weɪst.

Djevik K'Shar (DJEH-vihk KEH-SHAHR): In the Trolloc tongue, "The Dying Ground." The Trolloc name for the Aiel Waste.

doʊmən, beɪl (doʊ-moʊn, beɪl): ðə kæptən ə ðə spɹeɪ.

Domon, Bayle (DOH-mon, BAIL): The captain of the Spray.

dʒɹæɡən, ðə: ðə neɪm baɪ wɪtʃ luz θɝɪn tɛləmən wɑz noʊn dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. ɪn ðə mædnəs wɪtʃ oʊvɝtʊk ɔl meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, luz θɝɪn kɪld ɛvɹi lɪvɪŋ pɝsən u kæɹiɾ ɛni ʌv ɪz blʌd, əz wɛl əz ɛvɹiwʌn i lʌvd, ðʌs ɝnɪŋ ðə neɪm kɪnsleɪɝ. ə seɪɪŋ ɪz naʊ juzd, "teɪkən baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən," əɹ "pəzɛst ə ðə dʒɹæɡən," tə ɪndəkeɪt ðət sʌmwʌn ɪz ɛndeɪnʒɝɪŋ ðoʊz ɝaʊn ɪm əɹ θɹɛɾənɪŋ ðɛm, ɪspɛʃli ɪf wɪθaʊt kɑz. si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

Dragon, the: The name by which Lews Therin Telamon was known during the War of the Shadow. In the madness which overtook all male Aes Sedai, Lews Therin killed every living person who carried any of his blood, as well as everyone he loved, thus earning the name Kinslayer. A saying is now used, "taken by the Dragon," or "possessed of the Dragon," to indicate that someone is endangering those around him or threatening them, especially if without cause. See also Dragon Reborn.

dʒɹæɡən, fɔls: əkeɪʒənəli mɛn kleɪm tə bi ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn, ən səmtaɪmz wʌn ə ðɛm ɡeɪnz fɑloʊɪŋ ɪnʌf tə ɹikwaɪɝ ən ɑɹmi tə pʊɾ ɪt daʊn. səm əv bɪɡʌn wɔɹz ðəɾ ɪnvɑlv mɛni neɪʃənz. oʊvɝ ðə sɛntʃɝiz moʊst əv bɪn mɛn əneɪbəl tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ, bʌɾ ə fju kʊd. ɔl, haʊɛvɝ, iðɝ dɪsəpɪɹd, əɹ wɝ kæptʃɝɾ əɹ kɪld, wɪθaʊt fʊlfɪlɪŋ ɛni ʌv ðə pɹɑfəsiz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə ɹibɝθ ə ðə dʒɹæɡən. ðiz mɛn ɑɹ kɔl fɔls dʒɹæɡənz. si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn.

Dragon, false: Occasionally men claim to be the Dragon Reborn, and sometimes one of them gains following enough to require an army to put it down. Some have begun wars that involved many nations. Over the centuries most have been men unable to channel the One Power, but a few could. All, however, either disappeared, or were captured or killed, without fulfilling any of the Prophecies concerning the Rebirth of the Dragon. These men are called false Dragons. See also Dragon Reborn.

dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn: əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə pɹɑfəsi ən lɛdʒən ðə dʒɹæɡən wɪl bi bɔɹn əɡɛn ət mænkaɪnz ɡɹeɪɾəst aʊɝ ə nid tə seɪv ðə wɝld. ðɪs ɪz nɑt sʌmθɪŋ pipəl lʊk fɔɹwɝd tə, boʊθ kəz ðə pɹɑfəsiz seɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn wɪl bɹɪŋ ənu bɹeɪkɪŋ tə ðə wɝld, ən kəz luz θɝɪn kɪnsleɪɝ, ðə dʒɹæɡən, ɪz ə neɪm tə meɪk mɛn ʃʌɾɝ, ivən mɔɹ ðən θɹi θaʊzən jɪɹz æftɝ ɪz dɛθ. si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən, ðə; dʒɹæɡən, fɔls.

Dragon Reborn: According to prophecy and legend the Dragon will be born again at mankind's greatest hour of need to save the world. This is not something people look forward to, both because the prophecies say the Dragon Reborn will bring anew Breaking to the world, and because Lews Therin Kinslayer, the Dragon, is a name to make men shudder, even more than three thousand years after his death. See also Dragon, the; Dragon, false.

dʒɹæɡənz fæŋ, ðə: ə staɪlaɪz mɑɹk, juʒəwəli blæk, ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə tɪɹdʒɹɑp bælənst ɑn ɪts pɔɪnt. skɹɔld ɑn ə dɔɹ əɹ ə haʊs, ɪts ən ækjəzeɪʃən ʌv ivəl əɡɛns ðə pipəl ɪnsaɪd.

Dragon's Fang, the: A stylized mark, usually black, in the shape of a teardrop balanced on its point. Scrawled on a door or a house, it is an accusation of evil against the people inside.

dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz: ðoʊz mɛn ən wɪmən hu, eɪbəl tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ, wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə ʃædoʊ dʊɹɪŋ ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz, æktɪŋ əz kəmændɝz ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk fɔɹsɪz.

Dreadlords: Those men and women who, able to channel the One Power, went over to the Shadow during the Trolloc Wars, acting as commanders of the Trolloc forces.

isɑɹ; kɪŋ isɑɹ ə haʊs toʊdʒiɾə (i-zɑɹ; toʊ-ɡi-tɑ): kɪŋ ə ʃaɪnɝ. hɪz saɪ ɪz ə waɪt hɑɹt, wɪtʃ əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ʃaɪnɝən kʌstəm ɪz hɛld ɔlsoʊ tə bi ə saɪn ə ʃaɪnɝ əlɔŋ wɪð ðə blæk hɔk.

Easar; King Easar of House Togita (EE-zar; toh-GHEE-tah): King of Shienar. His sigh is a white hart, which according to Shienaran custom is held also to be a sign of Shienar along with the Black Hawk.

ɪleɪɾə (ɛ-laɪ-dɑ): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ hu ædvaɪzɪz kwin mɔɹɡeɪs ʌv ændɝ.

Elaida (eh-LY-da): An Aes Sedai who advises Queen Morgase of Andor.

ɪleɪn (i-leɪn): kwin mɔɹɡeɪsəz dɔɾɝ, ðə dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ tə ðə θɹoʊn ʌv ændɝ. hɝ saɪn ɪz ə ɡoʊldən lɪli.

Elayne (ee-LAIN): Queen Morgase's daughter, the Daughter-heir to the Throne of Andor. Her sign is a golden lily.

ɛls; ɛls ɡɹɪnwɛl ( ɡɹɪn-wɛl): ə fɑɹmɝz dɔɾɝ mɛɾ ɑn ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd.

Else; Else Grinwell (EHLZ GRIHN-wehl): A farmer's daughter met on the Caemlyn Road.

aɪləs, ðəsi mɹdʒɹɑl.

Eyeless, the:See Myrddraal.

feɪdsi mɹdʒɹɑl.

Fade:See Myrddraal.

feɪn, pdən (feɪn, pɑd-æn): ə pɛdlɝ u ɝaɪvz ɪn ɛmənz fil dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ wɪntɝnaɪt.

Fain, Padan (FAIN, PAHD-ahn): A peddler who arrives in Emond's Field just before Winternight.

fɑɹ dɛɹiz maɪ (fɑɹ dɑ-ɹaɪz maɪ): lɪɾɝəli, "meɪɾənz ə ðə spɪɹ." wʌn ʌv ə nʌmbɝ ʌv wɔɹiɝ səsaɪəɾiz ə ði il; ənlaɪk ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz, ɪɾ ədmɪts wɪmən ən oʊnli wɪmən. eɪ meɪɾən meɪ nɑt mɛɹi ən ɹɪmeɪn ɪn ðə səsaɪəɾi, nɔɹ meɪ ʃi faɪt waɪl kæɹiɪŋ ə tʃaɪld. ɛni tʃaɪl bɔɹn tə ə meɪɾən ɪz ɡɪvən tə ənʌðɝ wʊmən tə ɹeɪz, ɪn sətʃ ə weɪ ðət noʊ wʌn noʊz u ðə tʃaɪlz mʌðɝ wɑz. ("ju meɪ bɪlɔŋ tə noʊ mæn, nɔɹ meɪ ɛni mæn bɪlɔŋ tə ju, nɔɹ ɛni tʃaɪld. ðə spɪɹ ɪz jəɹ lʌvɝ, jəɹ tʃaɪld, ən jəɹ laɪf.") ðiz tʃɪlʒɹən ɑɹ tʃɹɛʒɝd, fəɹ ɪts pɹɑfəsaɪd ðəɾ ə tʃaɪl bɔɹn ʌv ə meɪɾən wɪl junaɪt ðə klænz ən ɹɪtɝn tə ði il tə ðə ɡɹeɪtnəs ðeɪ nu dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz.

Far Dareis Mai (FAHR DAH-rize MY): Literally, "Maidens of the Spear." One of a number of warrior societies of the Aiel; unlike any of the others, it admits women and only women. A Maiden may not marry and remain in the society, nor may she fight while carrying a child. Any child born to a Maiden is given to another woman to raise, in such a way that no one knows who the child's mother was. ("You may belong to no man, nor may any man belong to you, nor any child. The spear is your lover, your child, and your life.") These children are treasured, for it is prophesied that a child born of a Maiden will unite the clans and return to the Aiel to the greatness they knew during the Age of Legends.

fɑɹstʃɹaɪɾɝ, dʒaɪn (dʒeɪ-ɪn): ə hɪɹoʊ ʌv ðə nɔɹðɝn lænz u dʒɝnid tə mɛni lænz ən hæd mɛni ædvɛntʃɝz; ði ɔθɝ ə sɛvɹəl bʊks, əz wɛl əz biɪŋ ðə sʌbʒɪkt ə bʊks ən stɔɹiz. hi vænɪʃt ɪn naɪnhʌnʒɹədeɪtiwʌn ni, æftɝ ɹɪtɝnɪŋ fɹəm ə tʃɹɪp ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt wɪtʃ səm seɪ hæd teɪkən ɪm ɔl ðə weɪ tə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl.

Farstrider, Jain (JAY-ihn): A hero of the northern lands who journeyed to many lands and had many adventures; the author of several books, as well as being the subject of books and stories. He vanished in 981 NE, after returning from a trip into the Great Blight which some say had taken him all the way to Shayol Ghul.

fɑðɝ ə laɪzsi dɑɹk wʌn.

Father of Lies:See Dark One.

fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd: taɪɾəl nɔɹməli hɛl baɪ ði ɛldəs bɹʌðɝ ə ðə kwin ʌv ændɝ, hu hæz bɪn tʃɹeɪn sɪns tʃaɪldhʊd tə kəmæn ðə kwinz ɑɹmiz ɪn taɪm ʌv wɔɹ ən tə bi hɝ ædvaɪzɝ ɪn taɪm ə pis. ɪf ðə kwin əz noʊ sɝvaɪvɪŋ bɹʌðɝ, ʃɪl əpɔɪn sʌmwʌn tə ðət taɪɾəl.

First Prince of the Sword: Title normally held by the eldest brother of the Queen of Andor, who has been trained since childhood to command the Queen's armies in time of war and to be her adviser in time of peace. If the Queen has no surviving brother, she will appoint someone to that title.

fɪst: ðə beɪsɪk mɪlətɛɹi junəɾ ə ðə tʃɹɑləks, vɛɹiɪŋ ɪn nʌmbɝ; ɔlweɪz mɔɹ ðən wʌn hʌnʒɹəd, bʌt nɛvɝ mɔɹ ðən tu hʌnʒɹəd. ə fɪst ɪz juʒəwəli, bʌt nɑɾ ɔlweɪz, kəmændəd baɪ ə mɹdʒɹɑl.

fist: The basic military unit of the Trollocs, varying in number; always more than one hundred, but never more than two hundred. A fist is usually, but not always, commanded by a Myrddraal.

faɪv paʊɝz, ðə: ðəɹ ɑɹ θɹɛdz tə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ən itʃ pɝsən u kən tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ kən juʒəwəli ɡɹæsp səm θɹɛdz bɛɾɝ ðən ʌðɝz. ðiz θɹɛdz ɑɹ neɪmd əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə ðə sɔɹts ə θɪŋz ðət kən bi dʌn ʌndɝ əm - ɝθ, ɛɹ, faɪɝ, wɔɾɝ, ən spɪɹət - ən ɑɹ kɔl ðə faɪv paʊɝz. ɛni wildɝ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɪl əv ə ɡɹeɪɾɝ dɪɡɹi ʌv stʃɹɛŋkθ wɪð wʌn, əɹ pɑsəbli tu, ʌv ðiz, ən lɛsɝ stʃɹɛŋkθ ɪn ði ʌðɝz. səm fju meɪ hæv ɡɹeɪt stʃɹɛŋkθ wɪð θɹi, bʌt sɪns ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz noʊ wʌn əz hæd ɡɹeɪt stʃɹɛŋkθ wɪð ɔl faɪv. ivən ðən ðɪs wɑz ɪkstʃɹimli ɹɛɹ. ðə dɪɡɹi ʌv stʃɹɛŋkθ kən vɛɹi ɡɹeɪtli bɪtwin ɪndəvɪdʒəwəlz, soʊ ðət səm u kən tʃænəl ɑɹ mʌtʃ stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ʌðɝz. pɝfɔɹmɪŋ sɝɾən æks wɪð ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɹikwaɪɝz əbɪləɾi ɪn wʌn əɹ mɔɹ ə ðə faɪv paʊɝz. fəɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, stɑɹɾɪŋ əɹ kəntʃɹoʊlɪŋ ə faɪɝ ɹikwaɪɝz faɪɝ, ən əfɛktɪŋ ðə wɛðɝ ɹikwaɪɝz ɛɹ ən wɔɾɝ, waɪl hilɪŋ ɹikwaɪɝz wɔɾɝ ən spɪɹət. waɪl spɪɹət wɑz faʊn ikwəli ɪn mɛn ən ɪn wɪmən, ɡɹeɪɾ əbɪləɾi wɪð ɝθ ænslæʃɔɹ faɪɝ wɑz faʊn mʌtʃ mɔɹ ɔfən əmʌŋ mɛn, wɪð wɔɾɝ ænslæʃɔɹ ɛɹ əmʌŋ wɪmən. ðəɹ wɝ ɪksɛpʃənz, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz soʊ ɔfən soʊ ðəɾ ɝθ ən faɪɝ keɪm tə bi ɹəɡɑɹɾəd əz meɪl paʊɝz, ɛɹ ən wɔɾɝ əz fimeɪl. dʒɛnɝəli, noʊ əbɪləɾi ɪz kənsɪɾɝd stʃɹɔŋɝ ðən ɛni ʌðɝ, ðoʊ ðəɹ ɪz ə seɪɪŋ əmʌŋ ɛɛs sədaɪ: "ðɛɹ ɪz noʊ ɹɑk soʊ stʃɹɔŋ ðət wɔɾɝ ən wɪn kænɑt wɛɹ ɪɾ əweɪ, noʊ faɪɝ soʊ fɪɹs ðət wɔɾɝ kænɑt kwɛntʃ ɪɾ əɹ wɪn snʌf ɪɾ aʊt." ɪt ʃəd bi noʊɾəd ðɪs seɪɪŋ keɪm ɪndə jus lɔŋ æftɝ ðə læs meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ wɑz dɛd. ɛni ɪkwɪvələn seɪɪŋ əmʌŋ meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ ɪz lɔŋ lɔst.

Five Powers, the: There are threads to the One Power, and each person who can channel the One Power can usually grasp some threads better than others. These threads are named according to the sorts of things that can be done under them - Earth, Air, Fire, Water, and Spirit - and are called the Five Powers. Any wielder of the One Power will have a greater degree of strength with one, or possibly two, of these, and lesser strength in the others. Some few may have great strength with three, but since the Age of Legends no one has had great strength with all five. Even then this was extremely rare. The degree of strength can vary greatly between individuals, so that some who can channel are much stronger than others. Performing certain acts with the One Power requires ability in one or more of the Five Powers. For example, starting or controlling a fire requires Fire, and affecting the weather requires Air and Water, while Healing requires Water and Spirit. While Spirit was found equally in men and in women, great ability with Earth and/or Fire was found much more often among men, with Water and/or Air among women. There were exceptions, but it was so often so that Earth and Fire came to be regarded as male Powers, Air and Water as female. Generally, no ability is considered stronger than any other, though there is a saying among Aes Sedai: "There is no rock so strong that water and wind cannot wear it away, no fire so fierce that water cannot quench it or wind snuff it out." It should be noted this saying came into use long after the last male Aes Sedai was dead. Any equivalent saying among male Aes Sedai is long lost.

fleɪm ə tɑɹ vəlɑn: ðə sɪmbəl ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ən ði ɛɛs sədaɪ. ə staɪlaɪzd ɹɛpɝ sɛn tɑ ʃən ʌv ə fleɪm; ə waɪt tɪɹdʒɹɑp wɪð ðə pɔɪn ʌpwɝd.

Flame of Tar Valon: The symbol of Tar Valon and the Aes Sedai. A stylized repre sen ta tion of a flame; a white teardrop with the point upward.

fɔɹseɪkən, ðə: neɪm ɡɪvən tə θɝtin ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ɛɛs sədaɪ ɛvɝ noʊn, hu wɛn oʊvɝ tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ ɪn ɹɪtɝn fəɹ ðə pɹɑməs ʌv ɪmɔɹtælɪɾi. əkɔɹɾɪŋ tə boʊθ lɛdʒən ən fɹæɡməntɛɹi ɹɛkɝdz, ðeɪ wɝ ɪmpɹɪzən əlɔŋ wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn wən ɪz pɹɪzən wɑz ɹisiɾɪd. ðɛɹ neɪmz ɑɹ stɪl juz tə fɹaɪɾən tʃɪlʒɹən.

Forsaken, the: Name given to thirteen of the most powerful Aes Sedai ever known, who went over to the Dark One during the War of the Shadow in return for the promise of immortality. According to both legend and fragmentary records, they were imprisoned along with the Dark One when his prison was reseated. Their names are still used to frighten children.

ɡɑləd (ɡɑ-lɑd): si dəmədʒɹd, lɔɹd ɡɑleɪdɛdʒɹəd.

Galad (gah-LAHD): See Damodred, Lord Galadedrid.

ɡɔɪn (ɡɑ-wɪn): kwin mɔɹɡeɪsəz sʌn, ɪleɪnz bɹʌðɝ, hu wɪl bi fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd wən ɪleɪn əsɛnz ðə θɹoʊn. hɪz saɪn ɪz ə waɪt bɔɹ.

Gawyn (GAH-wihn): Queen Morgase's son, Elayne's brother, who will be First Prince of the Sword when Elayne ascends the throne. His sign is a white boar.

dʒɛntəlɪŋ: ði ækt, pɝfɔɹm baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʌv ʃʌɾɪŋ ɔf ə meɪl u kən tʃænəl fɹəm ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ðɪs ɪz nɛsəsɛɹi kəz ɛni mæn u lɝnz tə tʃænəl wɪl ɡoʊ ɪnseɪn fɹəm ðə teɪn əpɑn seɪɾɪn ən wɪl ɔlmoʊst sɝɾənli də hɔɹəbəl θɪŋz wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn ɪz mædnəs. ə mæn u hæz bɪn dʒɛntəl kən stɪl sɛns ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs, bʌɾ i kænɑt tʌtʃ ɪt. wʌtɛvɝ mædnəs əz kʌm bɪfɔɹ dʒɛntəlɪŋ ɪz ɝɛstəd baɪ ði ækt ə dʒɛntəlɪŋ, bʌt nɑt kjʊɹd baɪ ɪt, ən ɪf ɪts dʌn sun ɪnʌf dɛθ kən bi əvɝɾəd.

gentling: The act, performed by Aes Sedai, of shutting off a male who can channel from the One Power. This is necessary because any man who learns to channel will go insane from the taint upon saidin and will almost certainly do horrible things with the Power in his madness. A man who has been gentled can still sense the True Source, but he cannot touch it. Whatever madness has come before gentling is arrested by the act of gentling, but not cured by it, and if it is done soon enough death can be averted.

ɡlimən: ə tʃɹævlɪŋ stɔɹitɛlɝ, mjuzɪʃən, dʒʌɡəlɝ, tʌmblɝ ən ɔl-ɝaʊn ɛntɝteɪnɝ. noʊn baɪ ðɛɹ tʃɹeɪdmɑɹk kloʊks ə mɛni-kʌlɝd pætʃəz, ðeɪ pɝfɔɹm meɪnli ɪn ðə vɪlədʒəz ən smɔlɝ taʊnz, sɪns lɑɹdʒɝ taʊnz ən sɪɾiz əv ʌðɝ ɛntɝteɪnməns əveɪləbəl.

gleeman: A traveling storyteller, musician, juggler, tumbler and all-around entertainer. Known by their trademark cloaks of many-colored patches, they perform mainly in the villages and smaller towns, since larger towns and cities have other entertainments available.

ɡɹeɪt blaɪt, ðə: ə ɹidʒən ɪn ðə fɑɹ nɔɹθ, ɪntaɪɝli kɝʌptɪd baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌn. ə hɔn ə tʃɹɑləks, mɹdʒɹɑl, ən ʌðɝ kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn.

Great Blight, the: A region in the far north, entirely corrupted by the Dark One. A haunt of Trollocs, Myrddraal, and other creatures of the Dark One.

ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn, ðə: ə saɪkəl ə stɔɹiz kənsɝnɪŋ ðə lɛdʒəndɛɹi sɝtʃ fəɹ ðə hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ, ɪn ðə jɪɹz bɪtwin ði ɛn ə ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz ən ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. ɪf toʊld ɪn ðɛɹ ɪntaɪɝɾi, ðə saɪkəl wəd teɪk mɛni deɪz.

Great Hunt of the Horn, the: A cycle of stories concerning the legendary search for the Horn of Valere, in the years between the end of the Trolloc Wars and the beginning of the War of the Hundred Years. If told in their entirety, the cycle would take many days.

ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk: ðə neɪm baɪ wɪtʃ dɑɹkfɹɛnz ɹəfɝ tə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, kleɪmɪŋ ðət tə juz ɪz tʃɹu neɪm wəd bi blæsfəməs.

Great Lord of the Dark: The name by which Darkfriends refer to the Dark One, claiming that to use his true name would be blasphemous.

ɡɹeɪt pæɾɝn: ðə wil ə taɪm wivz ðə pæɾɝnz ə ði eɪdʒəz ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪt pæɾɝn, wɪtʃ ɪz ðə hoʊl ʌv ɛɡzɪstəns ən ɹiæləɾi, pæst, pɹɛzən ən fjutʃɝ. ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz ðə leɪs ʌv eɪdʒəz. si ɔlsoʊ pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ; wil ə taɪm.

Great Pattern: The Wheel of Time weaves the Patterns of the Ages into the Great Pattern, which is the whole of existence and reality, past, present and future. Also known as the Lace of Ages. See also Pattern of an Age; Wheel of Time.

ɡɹeɪt sɝpənt: ə sɪmbəl fəɹ taɪm ən ɪtɝnəɾi, eɪntʃən bɪfɔɹ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz bɪɡæn, kənsɪstɪŋ ʌv ə sɝpən iɾɪŋ ɪts oʊn teɪl.

Great Serpent: A symbol for time and eternity, ancient before the Age of Legends began, consisting of a serpent eating its own tail.

hæfmənsi mɹdʒɹɑl.

Halfman:See Myrddraal.

hɔkwɪŋ, ɑɹɾɝ: ə lɛdʒəndɛɹi kɪŋ u junaɪɾəd ɔl ðə lænz wɛst ə ðə spaɪn ə ðə wɝld, əz wɛl əz səm lænz bɪɑn ði il weɪst. hi ivən sɛn ɑɹmiz əkɹɔs ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən, bʌɾ ɔl kɑntækt wɪð ðiz wɑz lɔst əɾ ɪz dɛθ, wɪtʃ sɛɾ ɔf ðə wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz. hɪz saɪn wɑz ə ɡoʊldən hɔk ɪn flaɪt. si ɔlsoʊ wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz.

Hawkwing, Artur: A legendary king who united all the lands west of the Spine of the World, as well as some lands beyond the Aiel Waste. He even sent armies across the Aryth Ocean, but all contact with these was lost at his death, which set off the War of the Hundred Years. His sign was a golden hawk in flight. See also War of the Hundred Years.

hɑɹtfæŋ; hɑɹtsbeɪnsi dɑɹk wʌn.

Heartfang; Heartsbane:See Dark One.

hɑɹtstoʊn: ən ɪndəstʃɹʌktɪbəl sʌbstəns kɹieɪɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ɛni noʊn fɔɹs juzd ɪn ən ətɛmp tə bɹeɪk ɪts əbzɔɹbd, meɪkɪŋ hɑɹtstoʊn stʃɹɔŋɝ.

heartstone: An indestructible substance created during the Age of Legends. Any known force used in an attempt to break it is absorbed, making heartstone stronger.

hɔɹn ə vəlɪɹ (vɑ-lɪɹ): ðə lɛdʒəndɛɹi əbdʒɛkt ə ðə ɡɹeɪt hʌn ə ðə hɔɹn. ðə hɔɹn səpoʊzədli kən kɔl bæk dɛd hɪɹoʊz fɹəm ðə ɡɹeɪv tə faɪɾ əɡɛns ðə ʃædoʊ.

Horn of Valere (vah-LEER): The legendary object of the Great Hunt of the Horn. The Horn supposedly can call back dead heroes from the grave to fight against the Shadow.

hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz, ðə: wʌn hʌnʒɹəd meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, əmʌŋ ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, hu, lɛd baɪ luz θɝɪn tɛləmən, lɔntʃt ðə faɪnəl stʃɹoʊk ðəɾ ɛndəd ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ baɪ silɪŋ ðə dɑɹk wʌn bæk ɪndə hɪz pɹɪzən. ðə dɑɹk wʌnz kaʊntɝstʃɹoʊk teɪntɪd seɪɾɪn; ðə hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz wɛn mæɾ ən bɪɡæn ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld.

Hundred Companions, the: One hundred male Aes Sedai, among the most powerful of the Age of Legends, who, led by Lews Therin Telamon, launched the final stroke that ended the War of the Shadow by sealing the Dark One back into his prison. The Dark One's counterstroke tainted saidin; the Hundred Companions went mad and began the Breaking of the World.

ɪljən (ɪl-li-æn): ə ɡɹeɪt pɔɹɾ ɑn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ðə neɪʃən ə ðə seɪm neɪm. ðə saɪn ʌv ɪljən ɪz naɪn ɡoʊldən biz ɑn ə fild ə dɑɹk ɡɹin.

Illian (IHL-lee-ahn): A great port on the Sea of Storms, capital city of the nation of the same name. The sign of Illian is nine golden bees on a field of dark green.

ɪŋtʃɹ; lɔɹɾ ɪŋtʃɹ ə haʊs ʃɪnoʊwə (ɪŋ-tɑɹ; ʃi-noʊ-wɑ): eɪ ʃaɪnɝən wɔɹiɝ mɛɾ ət fæl dæɹə.

Ingtar; Lord Ingtar of House Shinowa (IHNG-tahr; shih-NOH-wah): A Shienaran warrior met at Fal Dara.

kændɝ (kæn-dɔɹ): wʌn ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ðə saɪn ə kændɝ ɪz ə ɹɪɹɪŋ ɹɛd hɔɹs ɑn ə fild ə peɪl ɡɹin.

Kandor (KANH-dohr): One of the Borderlands. The sign of Kandor is a rearing red horse on a field of pale green.

kɪntʃ, haɪəm (, haɪ-ɑm): ə fɑɹmɝ mɛɾ ɑn ðə keɪɛmlɪn ɹoʊd.

Kinch, Hyam (KIHNCH, HY-ahm): A farmer met on the Caemlyn Road.

koʊbəl (koʊ-bɑl): si tʃɹɑləks.

Ko'bal (KOH-bahl): See Trollocs.

leɪs ʌv eɪdʒəzsi ɡɹeɪt pæɾɝn, ðə.

Lace of Ages:See Great Pattern, the.

læn; ælən mænʒɹɑɡɔɹən (ɑl-læn mæn-dʒɹæɡ-ɔɹ-æn): ə wɔɹiɝ fɹəm ðə nɔɹθ; mɔɪɹeɪnz kəmpænjən.

Lan; al'Lan Mandragoran (AHL-LAN man-DRAG-or-an): A warrior from the north; Moiraine's companion.

lifblaɪɾɝsi dɑɹk wʌn.

Leafblighter:See Dark One.

liɡ: ə mɛʒɝ ə dɪstəns ikwəl tə fɔɹ maɪlz. si ɔlsoʊ maɪl.

league: A measure of distance equal to four miles. See also mile.

luk; lɔɹd luk ə haʊs mæntʃɹ (luk; mæn-ti-ɑɹ): tɪɡɹeɪnz bɹʌðɝ, hu wʊɾə bɪn əɹ fɝs pɹɪns ə ðə sɔɹd wən ʃi əsɛndəd ðə θɹoʊn. hɪz dɪsəpɪɹəns ɪn ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪɾ ɪz bɪliv tə bi ɪn səm weɪ kənɛktəd tə tɪɡɹeɪnz leɪɾɝ dɪsəpɪɹəns. hɪz saɪn wɑz ən eɪkɔɹn.

Luc; Lord Luc of House Mantear (LUKE; MAN-tee-ahr): Tigraine's brother, who would have been her First Prince of the Sword when she ascended the throne. His disappearance in the Great Blight is believed to be in some way connected to Tigraine's later disappearance. His sign was an acorn.

lɝk (): si mɹdʒɹɑl.

Lurk (LUHRK): See Myrddraal.

mækɛɹə, ɛlaɪəs (mɑ-tʃɪɹ-ɑ, i-laɪ-ɑz): ə mæn ɪnkaʊntɝd baɪ pɛɹɪn ən ɛɡwin ɪn ðə fɔɹəst.

Machera, Elyas (mah-CHEER-ah, ee-LY-ahs): A man encountered by Perrin and Egwene in the forest.

mɑɾi (mɑ-di): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "sikɝ." taɪɾəl ə ðə liɾɝ ʌv ə tuætɑn kɑɹvən.

Mahdi (MAH-dee): In the Old Tongue, "Seeker." Title of the leader of a Tuatha'an carvan.

mɔlkiɝ (mɑl-kiɪɹ): ə neɪʃən, wʌns wʌn ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz, naʊ kənsum baɪ ðə blaɪt. ðə saɪn ə mɔlkiɝ wɑz ə ɡoʊldən kɹeɪn ɪn flaɪt.

Malkier (mahl-KEER): A nation, once one of the Borderlands, now consumed by the Blight. The sign of Malkier was a golden crane in flight.

mændɑɹb (mæn-dɑɹb): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "bleɪd."

Mandarb (MAHN-dahrb): In the Old Tongue, "Blade."

meɪnɛðɝən (mæn--ɛɹ-ɛn): wʌn ə ðə tɛn neɪʃənz ðət meɪd ðə sɛkən kʌvənənt, ən ɔlsoʊ ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv ðət neɪʃən. boʊθ sɪɾi ən neɪʃən wɝ ʌɾɝli dɪstʃɹɔɪɾ ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz.

Manetheren (mahn-EHTH-ehr-ehn): One of the Ten Nations that made the Second Covenant, and also the capital city of that nation. Both city and nation were utterly destroyed in the Trolloc Wars.

mɛɹədɑn (mɑ-ɹɑ-dɑn): ðə kæpəɾəl sɪɾi ʌv sɑldɑiə.

Maradon (MAH-rah-don): The capital city of Saldaea.

mɛɹɪlɪn, tɑm (mɛɹ-ɹɪ-lɪn, tɑm): ə ɡlimən u kʌmz tə ɛmənz fil tə pɝfɔɹm ət bɛl taɪn.

Merrilin, Thom (MER-rih-lihn, TOM): A gleeman who comes to Emond's Field to perform at Bel Tine.

maɪl: ə mɛʒɝ ə dɪstəns ikwəl tə wʌn θaʊzən spænz. fɔɹ maɪlz meɪk wʌn liɡ. si ɔlsoʊ spæn.

mile: A measure of distance equal to one thousand spans. Four miles make one league. See also span.

mɪn (mɪn): ə jʌŋ wʊmən ɪnkaʊntɝɾ ət ðə stæɡ ən laɪən ɪn bɛɹlən.

Min (MIN): A young woman encountered at the Stag and Lion in Baerlon.

mɔɪɹeɪn (mwɑ-ɹeɪn): ə vɪzəɾɝ tə ɛmənz fild u ɝaɪvz dʒʌs bɪfɔɹ wɪntɝnaɪt.

Moiraine (mwah-RAIN): A visitor to Emond's Field who arrives just before Winternight.

mɔɹɡeɪs (mʊɹ-ɡeɪz): baɪ ðə ɡɹeɪs ə ðə laɪt, kwin ʌv ændɝ, haɪ siɾ ə haʊs tʃɹəkənd (-ɑnd). hɝ saɪn ɪz θɹi ɡoʊldən kiz. ðə saɪn ə haʊs tʃɹəkən ɪz ə sɪlvɝ kistoʊn.

Morgase (moor-GAYZ): By the Grace of the Light, Queen of Andor, High Seat of House Trakand (TRAHK-ahnd). Her sign is three golden keys. The sign of House Trakand is a silver keystone.

mɹdʒɹɑl (-dʒɹɑl): kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, kəmændɝz ə ðə tʃɹɑləks. twɪstəɾ ɔfspɹɪŋ ə tʃɹɑləks ɪn wɪtʃ ðə hjumən stɑk juz tə kɹieɪt ðə tʃɹɑləks əz ɹisɝfəst, bʌt teɪntɪd baɪ ði ivəl ðət meɪd ðə tʃɹɑləks. fɪzɪkəli ðeɪ ɑɹ laɪk mɛn ɪksɛp ðət ðeɪv noʊ aɪz, bʌt kən si laɪk iɡəlz ɪn laɪɾ əɹ dɑɹk. ðeɪv sɝɾən paʊɝz stɛmɪŋ fɹəm ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ɪnkluɾɪŋ ði əbɪləɾi tə kɑz pɛɹəlaɪzɪŋ fɪɹ wɪð ə lʊk ən ði əbɪləɾi tə vænɪʃ wɛɹɛvɝ ðəɹ ɑɹ ʃædoʊz. wʌn ə ðɛɹ fju noʊn wiknəsəz ɪz ðət ðeɪ ɑɹ ɹɪlʌktən tə kɹɔs ɹʌnɪŋ wɔɾɝ. ɪn dɪfɹən lænz ðeɪ ɑɹ noʊn baɪ mɛni neɪmz, əmʌŋ əm hæfmən, ði aɪləs, ʃæɾoʊmən, lɝk, ən feɪd.

Myrddraal (MUHRD-draal): Creatures of the Dark One, commanders of the Trollocs. Twisted offspring of Trollocs in which the human stock used to create the Trollocs has resurfaced, but tainted by the evil that made the Trollocs. Physically they are like men except that they have no eyes, but can see like eagles in light or dark. They have certain powers stemming from the Dark One, including the ability to cause paralyzing fear with a look and the ability to vanish wherever there are shadows. One of their few known weaknesses is that they are reluctant to cross running water. In different lands they are known by many names, among them Halfmen, the Eyeless, Shadowmen, Lurk, and Fade.

wʌn paʊɝ, ðə: ðə paʊɝ dʒɹɔn fɹəm ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs. ðə væs mədʒɔɹəɾi ʌv pipəl ɑɹ kəmplitli əneɪbəl tə lɝn tə tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ. ə vɛɹi smɔl nʌmbɝ kən bi tɔt tə tʃænəl, ən ən ivən taɪniɝ nʌmbɝ əv ði əbɪləɾi ɪnbɔɹn. fəɹ ðiz fju ðəɹ ɪz noʊ nid tə bi tɔt; ðəl tʌtʃ ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ən tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ wɛðɝ ðeɪ wɑnə əɹ nɑt, pɝhæps wɪθaʊɾ ivən ɹilaɪzɪŋ wʌt ðeɪ ɑɹ duɪŋ. ðɪs ɪnbɔɹn əbɪləɾi juʒəwəli mænəfɛsts ɪtsɛlf ɪn leɪɾ æɾəlɛsəns əɹ ɝli ədʌlthʊd. ɪf kəntʃɹoʊl ɪz nɑt tɔt, əɹ sɛlf-lɝnd (ɪkstʃɹimli dɪfəkəlt, wɪð ə səksɛs ɹeɪɾ ʌv oʊnli wʌn ɪn fɔɹ), dɛθ ɪz sɝɾən. sɪns ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, noʊ mæn əz bɪn eɪbəl tə tʃænəl ðə paʊɝ wɪθaʊɾ ɪvɛntʃəwəli ɡoʊɪŋ kəmplitli, hɔɹəbli mæd; ən ðɛn, ivən ɪf hiz lɝn səm kəntʃɹoʊl, daɪɪŋ fɹəm ə weɪstɪŋ sɪknəs wɪtʃ kɑzəz ðə sʌfɝɝ tə ɹɑɾ əlaɪv - ə sɪknəs kɑzd, əz ɪz ðə mædnəs, baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz teɪn ɑn seɪɾɪn. fəɹ ə wʊmən ðə dɛθ ðət kʌmz wɪθaʊt kəntʃɹoʊl ə ðə paʊɝ ɪz lɛs hɔɹəbəl, bʌɾ ɪts dɛθ dʒʌs ðə seɪm. ɛɛs sədaɪ sɝtʃ fəɹ ɡɝlz wɪð ði ɪnbɔɹn əbɪləɾi əz mʌtʃ tə seɪv ðɛɹ laɪvz əz tə ɪnkɹis ɛɛs sədaɪ nʌmbɝz, ən fəɹ mɛn wɪð ɪɾ ɪn ɔɹɾɝ tə stɑp ðə tɛɹəbəl θɪŋz ðeɪ ɪnɛvəɾəbli də wɪð ðə paʊɝ ɪn ðɛɹ mædnəs. si ɔlsoʊ tʃænəl; taɪm ə mædnəs; tʃɹu sɔɹs.

One Power, the: The power drawn from the True Source. The vast majority of people are completely unable to learn to channel the One Power. A very small number can be taught to channel, and an even tinier number have the ability inborn. For these few there is no need to be taught; they will touch the True Source and channel the Power whether they want to or not, perhaps without even realizing what they are doing. This inborn ability usually manifests itself in late adolescence or early adulthood. If control is not taught, or self-learned (extremely difficult, with a success rate of only one in four), death is certain. Since the time of Madness, no man has been able to channel the Power without eventually going completely, horribly mad; and then, even if he has learned some control, dying from a wasting sickness which causes the sufferer to rot alive - a sickness caused, as is the madness, by the Dark One's taint on saidin. For a woman the death that comes without control of the Power is less horrible, but it is death just the same. Aes Sedai search for girls with the inborn ability as much to save their lives as to increase Aes Sedai numbers, and for men with it in order to stop the terrible things they inevitably do with the Power in their madness. See also channel; Time of Madness; True Source.

pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ: ðə wil ə taɪm wivz ðə θɹɛdz ə hjumən lɪvz ɪndə ðə pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ, wɪtʃ fɔɹmz ðə sʌbstəns ə ɹiæləɾi fəɹ ðəɾ eɪdʒ; ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz eɪdʒ leɪs. si ɔlsoʊ tɑvɝən.

Pattern of an Age: The Wheel of Time weaves the threads of human lives into the Pattern of an Age, which forms the substance of reality for that Age; also known as Age Lace. See also ta'veren.

kwɛstʃənɝz, ðə: ən ɔɹɾɝ wɪðɪn ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt. ðɛɹ əvaʊd pɝpəsəz ɑɹ dɪskʌvɝɪŋ ðə tʃɹuθ ɪn dɪspjəteɪʃənz ən ənkʌvɝɪŋ dɑɹkfɹɛnz. ɪn ðə sɝtʃ fəɹ tʃɹuθ ən ðə laɪt, əz ðeɪ si ɪt, ðeɪ ɑɹ ivən mɔɹ zɛləs ðən ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪɾ əz ə hoʊl. ðɛɹ nɔɹməl mɛθəɾ ʌv ɪnkwaɪɹi ɪz baɪ tɔɹtʃɝ; ðɛɹ nɔɹməl æɾətud ðət ðeɪ noʊ ðə tʃɹuθ ɔlɹɛɾi ən mʌst oʊnli meɪk ðɛɹ vɪktəm kənfɛs tə ɪt. ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɹəfɝ tə ðɛmsɛlvz əz ðə hæn ə ðə laɪt, ən ət taɪmz ækt əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ ɪntaɪɝli sɛpɹət fɹəm ðə tʃɪlʒɹən ən ðə kaʊnsəl ə ði ənɔɪntəd, wɪtʃ kəmænz ðə tʃɪlʒɹən. ðə hɛɾ ə ðə kwɛstʃənɝz ɪz ðə haɪ ɪnkwɪzəɾɝ, hu sɪts ɑn ðə kaʊnsəl ə ði ənɔɪntəd.

Questioners, the: An order within the Children of the Light. Their avowed purposes are discovering the truth in disputations and uncovering Darkfriends. In the search for truth and the Light, as they see it, they are even more zealous than the Children of the Light as a whole. Their normal method of inquiry is by torture; their normal attitude that they know the truth already and must only make their victim confess to it. The Questioners refer to themselves as the Hand of the Light, and at times act as if they were entirely separate from the Children and the Council of the Anointed, which commands the Children. The head of the Questioners is the High Inquisitor, who sits on the Council of the Anointed.

ɹɛɾ ədʒɑsi ədʒɑ.

Red Ajah:See Ajah.

sɑŋɡɹil (sɑ-æn-ɡɹi-ɑl): ən ɪkstʃɹimli ɹɛɹ ɑbʒɛkt wɪtʃ əlaʊz ən ɪndəvɪdʒəwəl tə tʃænəl mʌtʃ mɔɹ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ðən wəɾ ʌðɝwaɪz bi pɑsəbəl əɹ seɪf. ə sɑŋɡɹil ɪz laɪk ʌntu, bʌt mʌtʃ, mʌtʃ mɔɹ paʊɝfəl ðæn, ən æŋɡɹil. ɹɛmnəns ə ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz, ðə minz ə ðɛɹ meɪkɪŋ ɪz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ noʊn.

sa'angreal (SAH-ahn-GREE-ahl): An extremely rare object which allows an individual to channel much more of the One Power than would otherwise be possible or safe. A sa'angreal is like unto, but much, much more powerful than, an angreal. Remnants of the Age of Legends, the means of their making is no longer known.

seɪaɪdɑɹ; seɪɾɪn (sɑ-ɪ-dɑɹ; sɑ-ɪ-din): si tʃɹu sɔɹs.

saidar; saidin (sah-ih-DAHR; sah-ih-DEEN): See True Source.

sɑldɑiə (sɑl-deɪ-i-ɑ): wʌn ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ðə saɪn ə sɑldɑiə ɪz θɹi sɪlvɝ fɪʃ ɑn ə fild ə dɑɹk blu.

Saldaea (sahl-DAY-ee-ah): One of the Borderlands. The sign of Saldaea is three silver fish on a field of dark blue.

si foʊk: ɪnhæbəɾənts ʌv aɪlənz ɪn ði ɛɹɪθ (ɑ-ɹɪθ) oʊʃən ən ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz, ðeɪ spɛn lɪɾəl taɪm ɑn ðoʊz aɪlənz, lɪvɪŋ moʊst ə ðɛɹ laɪvz ɑn ðɛɹ ʃɪps. moʊst si-bɔɹn tʃɹeɪɾ ɪz kæɹid baɪ ðə si foʊks ʃɪps.

Sea Folk: Inhabitants of islands in the Aryth (AH-rihth) Ocean and the Sea of Storms, they spend little time on those islands, living most of their lives on their ships. Most sea-borne trade is carried by the Sea Folk's ships.

sɛkən kʌvənənsi kʌvənən ə ðə tɛn neɪʃənz.

Second Covenant:See Covenant of the Ten Nations.

ʃɑɾɝ lɔɡəθ (ʃɑ-dɑɹ loʊ-ɡɑθ): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "ðə pleɪs wɛɹ ðə ʃædoʊ weɪts." ə sɪɾi əbændən ən ʃʌn sɪns ðə tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz. ɔlsoʊ kɔld "ʃædoʊz weɪɾɪŋ."

Shadar Logoth (SHAH-dahr LOH-goth): In the Old Tongue, "the Place Where the Shadow Waits." A city abandoned and shunned since the Trolloc Wars. Also called "Shadow's Waiting."

ʃæɾoʊmənsi mɹdʒɹɑl.

Shadowman:See Myrddraal.

ʃeɪtɑn (ʃeɪ-ɪ-tæn): si dɑɹk wʌn.

Shai'tan (SHAY-ih-TAN): See Dark One.

ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl (ʃeɪ-əl ɡul): ə maʊntən ɪn ðə blæstəd lænz, ðə saɪɾ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌnz pɹɪzən.

Shayol Ghul (SHAY-ol GHOOL): A mountain in the Blasted Lands, the site of the Dark One's prison.

ʃɛpɝɾ ə ðə naɪtsi dɑɹk wʌn.

Shepherd of the Night:See Dark One.

ʃɛɹiəm (ʃɪɹ-i-ɑm): ən ɛɛs sədaɪ, ʌv ðə blu ədʒɑ.

Sheriam (SHEER-ee-ahm): An Aes Sedai, of the Blue Ajah.

ʃaɪnɝ (ʃaɪ-nɑɹ): wʌn ə ðə bɔɹɾɝlændz. ðə saɪn ə ʃaɪnɝ ɪz ə stupɪŋ blæk hɔk.

Shienar (shy-NAHR): One of the Borderlands. The sign of Shienar is a stooping black hawk.

ʃoʊufə (ʃu-fɑ): ə ɡɑɹmən ə ði il, ə klɔθ, juʒəwəli ðə kʌlɝ ə sæn əɹ ɹɑk, ðət ɹæps ɝaʊn ðə hɛɾ ən nɛk, livɪŋ oʊnli ðə feɪs bɛɹ.

shoufa (SHOO-fah): A garment of the Aiel, a cloth, usually the color of sand or rock, that wraps around the head and neck, leaving only the face bare.

saɪtbɝnɝsi dɑɹk wʌn.

Sightburner:See Dark One.

spæn: ə mɛʒɝ ə dɪstəns ikwəl tə tu peɪsɪz. ə θaʊzən spænz meɪk ə maɪl.

span: A measure of distance equal to two paces. A thousand spans make a mile.

spaɪn ə ðə wɝld, ðə: ə taʊɝɪŋ maʊntən ɹeɪnʒ, wɪð oʊnli ə fju pæsəz, wɪtʃ sɛpɝeɪts ði il weɪs fɹəm ðə lænz tə ðə wɛst.

Spine of the World, the: A towering mountain range, with only a few passes, which separates the Aiel Waste from the lands to the west.

stɛɾɪŋ (stɛd-dɪŋ): ən oʊɡiɝ (oʊhaɪoʊ-ɡɪɹ) hoʊmlænd. mɛni stɛɾɪŋ əv bɪn əbændən sɪns ðə bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld. ðeɪ ɑɹ pɔɹtʃɹeɪɾ ɪn stɔɹi ən lɛdʒən əz heɪvənz, ən wɪð ɹizən. ðeɪ ɑɹ ʃildɪɾ ɪn səm weɪ, noʊ lɔŋɡɝ ʌndɝstʊd, soʊ ðət wɪðɪn əm noʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ kən tʃænəl ðə wʌn paʊɝ, nɔɹ ivən sɛns ðət ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs ɪɡzɪsts. ətɛmps tə wil ðə wʌn paʊɝ fɹəm aʊtsaɪɾ ə stɛɾɪŋ əv noʊ ɪfɛkt ɪnsaɪɾ ə stɛɾɪŋ baʊndɝi. noʊ tʃɹɑlɑk wɪl ɛntɝ ə stɛɾɪŋ ənlɛs dʒɹɪvən, ən ivən ə mɹdʒɹɑl wɪl də soʊ oʊnli ət ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst niɾ ən ðən wɪð ðə ɡɹeɪɾəst ɹɪlʌktəns ən dɪsteɪst. ivən dɑɹkfɹɛnz, ɪf tʃɹuli dɛɾəkeɪtəd, fil ənkʌmftəɹbəl wɪðɪn ə stɛɾɪŋ.

stedding (STEHD-ding): An Ogier (OH-geer) homeland. Many stedding have been abandoned since the Breaking of the World. They are portrayed in story and legend as havens, and with reason. They are shielded in some way, no longer understood, so that within them no Aes Sedai can channel the One Power, nor even sense that the True Source exists. Attempts to wield the One Power from outside a stedding have no effect inside a stedding boundary. No Trolloc will enter a stedding unless driven, and even a Myrddraal will do so only at the greatest need and then with the greatest reluctance and distaste. Even Darkfriends, if truly dedicated, feel uncomfortable within a stedding.

stoʊn ə tɛɹ: ðə fɔɹtʃɹəs ɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðə sɪɾi ʌv tɛɹ. sɛd tə bi ði ɝliəs fɔɹtʃɹəs bɪlt æftɝ ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, ən sɛd baɪ səm tə hæv bɪn bɪl dʊɹɪŋ ðə taɪm ə mædnəs. si ɔlsoʊ tiɹ.

Stone of Tear: The fortress guarding the city of Tear. Said to be the earliest fortress built after the Time of Madness, and said by some to have been built during the Time of Madness. See also Tear.

sʌndeɪ: ə fistdeɪ ən fɛstəvəl ɪn mɪdsʌmɝ, waɪdli sɛləbɹeɪɾəd.

Sunday: A feastday and festival in midsummer, widely celebrated.

təbæk (tɑ-): ə wid, waɪdli kʌltəveɪɾəd. ðə livz ʌv ɪt, wən dʒɹaɪɾ ən kjʊɹd, ɑɹ bɝn ɪn wʊɾən hoʊldɝz kɔl paɪps, ðə fjumz biɪŋ ɪnheɪld.

tabac (tah-BAHK): A weed, widely cultivated. The leaves of it, when dried and cured, are burned in wooden holders called pipes, the fumes being inhaled.

tɑlænvɝ, mɑɹɾɪn (tɑl-æn-vɔɹ, mɑɹ-tin): ɡɑɹdzmæn-lutɛnən ə ðə kwinz ɡɑɹd; mɛɾ ɪn keɪɛmlɪn.

Tallanvor, Martyn (TAHL-ahn-vohr, mahr-TEEN): Guardsman-Lieutenant of the Queen's Guard; met in Caemlyn.

tæmɹəleɪlən (tɑ-mɑɹ-ɑl-aɪ-lɛn): ɪn ði oʊl tʌŋ, "wɛb ə dɛstəni."
