ta'maral'ailen (tah-MAHR-ahl-EYE-lehn): In the Old Tongue, "Web of Destiny."

tænɹəl, ɑɹɾɝ pɛndʒɹæɡ (tæn-ɹi-ɑl, ɑɹ-tʃɹ peɪ-ɛn-dʒɹæɡ): si hɔkwɪŋ, ɑɹɾɝ.

Tanreall, Artur Paendrag (tahn-REE-ahl, AHR-tuhr PAY-ehn-DRAG): See Hawkwing, Artur.

tɑɹ vəlɑn (tɑɹ vɑ-lɑn): ə sɪɾi ɑn ən aɪlən ɪn ðə ɹɪvɝ ɛɹɪnɪn. ðə sɛntɝ ʌv ɛɛs sədaɪ paʊɝ, ən loʊkeɪʃən ə ði æmɪɝlɪn sit.

Tar Valon (TAHR VAH-lon): A city on an island in the River Erinin. The center of Aes Sedai power, and location of the Amyrlin Seat.

tɑvɝən (tɑ-vɪɹ-ɛn): ə pɝsən ɝaʊn hum ðə wil ə taɪm wivz ɔl sɝaʊndɪŋ laɪf-θɹɛdz, pɝhæps ɔl laɪf-θɹɛdz, tə fɔɹm ə wɛb ə dɛstəni. si ɔlsoʊ pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ.

ta'veren (tah-VEER-ehn): A person around whom the Wheel of Time weaves all surrounding life-threads, perhaps all life-threads, to form a Web of Destiny. See also Pattern of an Age.

tɛɹ (tɪɹ): ə ɡɹeɪt sipɔɹɾ ɑn ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz. ðə saɪn ə tiɹ ɪz θɹi waɪt kɹɛsəns ɑn ə fild ə ɹɛɾ ən ɡoʊld.

Tear (TEER): A great seaport on the Sea of Storms. The sign of Tear is three white crescents on a field of red and gold.

tɛləmən, luz θɝɪn (tɛl-ɑ-moʊn, luz θɛ-ɹɪn): si ɔlsoʊ dʒɹæɡən, ðə.

Telamon, Lews Therin (TEHL-ah-mon, LOOZ THEH-rihn): See also Dragon, the.

θɑkændɑɹ (θɑ-kɑn-dɑɹ): ən ɪtɝnəli fɑɡ-ʃɹaʊɾɪd væli bɪloʊ ðə sloʊps ə ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl.

Thakan'dar (thah-kahn-DAHR): An eternally fog-shrouded valley below the slopes of Shayol Ghul.

tɪɡɹeɪn (ti-ɡɹeɪn): əz dɔɾɝ-ɛɹ ʌv ændɝ, ʃi mɛɹid tɑɹɪŋɡeɪl dəmədʒɹɾ ən bɔɹ ɪz sʌn ɡɑleɪdɛdʒɹəd. hɝ dɪsəpɪɹəns ɪn naɪnhʌnʒɹədsɛvəntitu ni, ʃɔɹtli æftɝ əɹ bɹʌðɝ luk vænɪʃt ɪn ðə blaɪt, lɛd tə ðə stʃɹʌɡəl ɪn ændɝ kɔl ðə səksɛʃən, ən kɑz ði ɪvɛns ɪn kɛɹhin wɪtʃ ɪvɛntʃəwəli bɹɔɾ ɑn ði il wɔɹ. hɝ saɪn wɑz ə wʊmənz hænd ɡɹɪpɪŋ ə θɔɹni ɹoʊz-stɛm wɪð ə waɪt blɑsəm.

Tigraine (tee-GRAIN): As Daughter-heir of Andor, she married Taringail Damodred and bore his son Galadedrid. Her disappearance in 972 NE, shortly after her brother Luc vanished in the Blight, led to the struggle in Andor called the Succession, and caused the events in Cairhien which eventually brought on the Aiel War. Her sign was a woman's hand gripping a thorny rose-stem with a white blossom.

taɪm ə mædnəssi bɹeɪkɪŋ ə ðə wɝld, ðə.

Time of Madness:See Breaking of the World, the.

tɪŋkɝzsi tuætɑn.

Tinkers:See Tuatha'an.

tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəlsi tuætɑn.

Traveling People:See Tuatha'an.

tʃɹɑlɑk wɔɹz: ə sɪɹiz ʌv wɔɹz, bɪɡɪnɪŋ əbaʊt wʌnθaʊzən æb ən læstɪŋ mɔɹ ðən θɹi hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz, dʊɹɪŋ wɪtʃ tʃɹɑlɑk ɑɹmiz ɹævɪdʒ ðə wɝld. ɪvɛntʃəwəli ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ sleɪn əɹ dʒɹɪvən bæk ɪndə ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt, bʌt səm neɪʃənz sis tə ɪɡzɪst, waɪl ʌðɝz wɝ ɔlmoʊs dɪpɑpjəleɪɾɪd. ɔl ɹɛkɝdz ə ðə taɪm ɑɹ fɹæɡməntɛɹi. si ɔlsoʊ kʌvənən ə ðə tɛn neɪʃənz.

Trolloc Wars: A series of wars, beginning about 1000 AB and lasting more than three hundred years, during which Trolloc armies ravaged the world. Eventually the Trollocs were slain or driven back into the Great Blight, but some nations ceased to exist, while others were almost depopulated. All records of the time are fragmentary. See also Covenant of the Ten Nations.

tʃɹɑləks (tʃɹæl-loʊks): kɹitʃɝz ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn, kɹieɪɾəd dʊɹɪŋ ðə wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ. hjudʒ ɪn stætʃɝ, vɪʃəs ɪn ði ɪkstʃɹim, ðeɪ ɑɹ ə twɪstəd blɛn ʌv ænəməl ən hjumən stɑk, ən kɪl fəɹ ðə pjʊɹ plɛʒɝ ə kɪlɪŋ. slaɪ, dəsitfəl ən tʃɹɛtʃɝəs, ðeɪ kən bi tʃɹʌstɪɾ oʊnli baɪ ðoʊz ðeɪ fɪɹ. ðeɪ ɑɹ ɑmnɪvɝəs ən wɪl iɾ ɛni kaɪndə mit, ɪnkluɾɪŋ hjumən flɛʃ ən ðə flɛʃ ʌv ʌðɝ tʃɹɑləks. lɑɹdʒli ʌv hjumən ɔɹədʒən, ðeɪ ɑɹ eɪbəl tə ɪntɝbɹid wɪð hjumənkaɪnd, bʌt ði ɔfspɹɪŋ ɑɹ juʒəwəli stɪlbɔɹn, ən ðoʊz wɪtʃ ɑɹ nɑɾ ɔfən feɪl tə sɝvaɪv. ðeɪ ɑɹ dɪvaɪɾəd ɪndə tʃɹaɪb-laɪk bænz, tʃif əmʌŋ əm biɪŋ ði ɑfɹeɪt, ɑlɡhəl, bænʃin, dɑvɑl, deɪmən, dʒɪnən, ɡɑɹɡl, ɡɑblɪn, ɡoʊləm, ɹmlən, koʊbəl, ən ðə nɑmən.

Trollocs (TRAHL-lohks): Creatures of the Dark One, created during the War of the Shadow. Huge in stature, vicious in the extreme, they are a twisted blend of animal and human stock, and kill for the pure pleasure of killing. Sly, deceitful and treacherous, they can be trusted only by those they fear. They are omnivorous and will eat any kind of meat, including human flesh and the flesh of other Trollocs. Largely of human origin, they are able to interbreed with humankind, but the offspring are usually stillborn, and those which are not often fail to survive. They are divided into tribe-like bands, chief among them being the Ahf'frait, Al'ghol, Bhan'sheen, Dha'vol, Dhai'mon, Dhjin'nen, Ghar'ghael, Ghob'hlin, Gho'hlem, Ghraem'lan, Ko'bal, and the Kno'mon.

tʃɹu sɔɹs: ðə dʒɹaɪvɪŋ fɔɹs ə ðə junəvɝs, wɪtʃ tɝnz ðə wil ə taɪm. ɪts dɪvaɪɾəd ɪndə ə meɪl hæf (seɪɾɪn) ən ə fimeɪl hæf (seɪaɪdɑɹ), wɪtʃ wɝk ət ðə seɪm taɪm wɪð ən əɡɛnst itʃ ʌðɝ. oʊnli ə mæn kən dʒɹɔ ɑn seɪɾɪn, oʊnli ə wʊmən ɑn seɪaɪdɑɹ. sɪns ðə bɪɡɪnɪŋ ə ðə taɪm ə mædnəs, seɪɾɪn əz bɪn teɪntɪd baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz tʌtʃ. si ɔlsoʊ wʌn paʊɝ.

True Source: The driving force of the universe, which turns the Wheel of Time. It is divided into a male half (saidin) and a female half (saidar), which work at the same time with and against each other. Only a man can draw on saidin, only a woman on saidar. Since the beginning of the Time of Madness, saidin has been tainted by the Dark One's touch. See also One Power.

tuætɑn (tu-ɑ-θɑ-æn): ə wɑndɝɪŋ foʊk, ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz ðə tɪŋkɝz ən əz ðə tʃɹævlɪŋ pipəl, hu lɪv ɪn bɹaɪtli peɪntəd wæɡənz ən fɑloʊ ə toʊɾəli pæsɪfɪs fəlɑsəfi kɔl ðə weɪ ʌv ðə lif. θɪŋz mɛndɪd baɪ tɪŋkɝz ɑɹ ɔfən bɛɾɝ ðən nu, bʌt ðə tuætɑn ɑɹ ʃʌn baɪ mɛni vɪlədʒəz kəz ə stɔɹiz ðət ðeɪ stil tʃɪlʒɹən ən tʃɹaɪ tə kənvɝt jʌŋ pipəl tə ðɛɹ bɪlifs.

Tuatha'an (too-AH-thah-AHN): A wandering folk, also known as the Tinkers and as the Traveling People, who live in brightly painted wagons and follow a totally pacifist philosophy called the Way of the Leaf. Things mended by Tinkers are often better than new, but the Tuatha'an are shunned by many villages because of stories that they steal children and try to convert young people to their beliefs.

vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl: ɪn moʊs vɪlədʒəz ə ɡɹup ə mɛn, ɪlɛktəd baɪ ðə taʊnsmɪn ən hɛɾəd baɪ ə meɪɝ, hu ɑɹ ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ meɪkɪŋ dɪsɪʒənz wɪtʃ əfɛk ðə vɪlədʒ əz ə hoʊl ən fəɹ nɪɡoʊʃieɪɾɪŋ wɪð ðə kaʊnsəlz ʌv ʌðɝ vɪlədʒəz oʊvɝ mæɾɝz wɪtʃ əfɛk ðə vɪlədʒəz dʒɔɪnli. ðeɪ ɑɹ əɾ ɑdz wɪð ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl ɪn soʊ mɛni vɪlədʒəz ðət ðɪs kɑnflɪkt ɪz sin əz ɔlmoʊs tʃɹədɪʃənəl. si ɔlsoʊ wɪmənz sɝkəl.

Village Council: In most villages a group of men, elected by the townsmen and headed by a Mayor, who are responsible for making decisions which affect the village as a whole and for negotiating with the Councils of other villages over matters which affect the villages jointly. They are at odds with the Women's Circle in so many villages that this conflict is seen as almost traditional. See also Women's Circle.

wɔɹ ə ðə hʌnʒɹəd jɪɹz: ə sɪɹiz ʌv oʊvɝlæpɪŋ wɔɹz əmʌŋ kɑnstənli ʃɪftɪŋ əlaɪənsəz, pɹɪsɪpɪteɪɾɪd baɪ ðə dɛθ ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ ən ðə ɹɪzʌltɪŋ stʃɹʌɡəl fəɹ ɪz ɛmpaɪɝ. ɪt læstəd fɹəm fi naɪnhʌnʒɹədnaɪntifɔɹ tə fi wʌnθaʊzəndwʌnhʌnʒɹədsɛvəntin. ðə wɔɹ dɪpɑpjəleɪɾɪd lɑɹdʒ pɑɹts ə ðə lænz bɪtwin ði ɛɹɪθ oʊʃən ən ði il weɪst, fɹəm ðə si ʌv stɔɹmz tə ðə ɡɹeɪt blaɪt. soʊ ɡɹeɪt wɑz ðə dɪstʃɹʌkʃən ðəɾ oʊnli fɹæɡməntɛɹi ɹɛkɝdz ə ðə taɪm ɹɪmeɪn. ði ɛmpaɪɝ ʌv ɑɹɾɝ hɔkwɪŋ wɑz pʊld əpɑɹt, ən ðə neɪʃənz ə ðə pɹɛzən deɪ wɝ fɔɹmd.

War of the Hundred Years: A series of overlapping wars among constantly shifting alliances, precipitated by the death of Artur Hawkwing and the resulting struggle for his empire. It lasted from FY 994 to FY 1117. The war depopulated large parts of the lands between the Aryth Ocean and the Aiel Waste, from the Sea of Storms to the Great Blight. So great was the destruction that only fragmentary records of the time remain. The empire of Artur Hawkwing was pulled apart, and the nations of the present day were formed.

wɔɹ ə ðə ʃædoʊ: ɔlsoʊ noʊn əz ðə wɔɹ ə paʊɝ, ɪɾ ɛndəd ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz. ɪt bɪɡæn ʃɔɹtli æftɝ ði ətɛmp tə fɹi ðə dɑɹk wʌn, ən sun ɪnvɑlv ðə hoʊl wɝld. ɪn ə wɝld wɛɹ ivən ðə mɛmɹi ʌv wɔɹ hæd bɪn fɝɡɑɾən, ɛvɹi fæsəɾ ʌv wɔɹ wɑz ɹiɾɪskʌvɝd, ɔfən twɪstəd baɪ ðə dɑɹk wʌnz tʌtʃ ɑn ðə wɝld, ən ðə wʌn paʊɝ wɑz juzd əz ə wɛpən. ðə wɔɹ wɑz ɛndəd baɪ ðə ɹisilɪŋ ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn ɪndə hɪz pɹɪzən.

War of the Shadow: Also known as the War of Power, it ended the Age of Legends. It began shortly after the attempt to free the Dark One, and soon involved the whole world. In a world where even the memory of war had been forgotten, every facet of war was rediscovered, often twisted by the Dark One's touch on the World, and the One Power was used as a weapon. The war was ended by the resealing of the Dark One into his prison.

wɔɹɾɝ: ə wɔɹiɝ bɑndəd tə ən ɛɛs sədaɪ. ðə bɑndɪŋ ɪz ə θɪŋ ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ, ən baɪ ɪɾ i ɡeɪnz sətʃ ɡɪfs əz kwɪk hilɪŋ, ði əbɪləɾi tə ɡoʊ lɔŋ pɪɹiədz wɪθaʊt fud, wɔɾɝ əɹ ɹɛst, ən ði əbɪləɾi tə sɛns ðə teɪn ə ðə dɑɹk wʌn əɾ ə dɪstəns. soʊ lɔŋ əz ə wɔɹɾɝ lɪvz, ði ɛɛs sədaɪ tə hum hiz bɑndəd noʊz hiz əlaɪv haʊɛvɝ fɑɹ əweɪ hi ɪz, ən wən i daɪz ʃɪl noʊ ðə moʊmən ən mænɝ ə hɪz dɛθ. waɪl moʊst ədʒəz bɪliv ən ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ hæv wʌn wɔɹɾɝ bɑndəd tə hɝ əɾ ə taɪm, ðə ɹɛɾ ədʒɑ ɹəfjuzəz tə bɑn ɛni wɔɹɾɝz əɾ ɔl, waɪl ðə ɡɹin ədʒɑ bɪlivz ən ɛɛs sədaɪ meɪ bɑn əz mɛni wɔɹɾɝz əz ʃi wɪʃɪz. ɛθɪkəli ðə wɔɹɾɝ mʌst æksid tə ðə bɑndɪŋ, bʌɾ ɪts bɪn noʊn tə bi dʌn ɪnvoʊlʌntɝɪli. wʌt ði ɛɛs sədaɪ ɡeɪn fɹəm ðə bɑndɪŋ ɪz ə kloʊsli-hɛl sikɹət. si ɔlsoʊ ɛɛs sədaɪ.

Warder: A warrior bonded to an Aes Sedai. The bonding is a thing of the One Power, and by it he gains such gifts as quick healing, the ability to go long periods without food, water or rest, and the ability to sense the taint of the Dark One at a distance. So long as a Warder lives, the Aes Sedai to whom he is bonded knows he is alive however far away he is, and when he dies she will know the moment and manner of his death. While most Ajahs believe an Aes Sedai may have one Warder bonded to her at a time, the Red Ajah refuses to bond any Warders at all, while the Green Ajah believes an Aes Sedai may bond as many Warders as she wishes. Ethically the Warder must accede to the bonding, but it has been known to be done involuntarily. What the Aes Sedai gain from the bonding is a closely-held secret. See also Aes Sedai.

wɛb ə dɛstəni: ə ɡɹeɪt tʃeɪnʒ ɪn ðə pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ, sɛntɝɾ ɝaʊnd wʌn əɹ mɔɹ pipəl u ɑɹ tɑvɝən.

Web of Destiny: A great change in the Pattern of an Age, centered around one or more people who are ta'veren.

wil ə taɪm, ðə: taɪm ɪz ə wil wɪð sɛvən spoʊks, itʃ spoʊk ən eɪdʒ. əz ðə wil tɝnz, ði eɪdʒəz kʌm ən ɡoʊ, itʃ livɪŋ mɛmɹiz ðət feɪd tə lɛdʒənd, ðən tə mɪθ, ən ɑɹ fɝɡɑɾən baɪ ðə taɪm ðəɾ eɪdʒ kʌmz əɡɛn. ðə pæɾɝn ʌv ən eɪdʒ ɪz slaɪtli dɪfɹən itʃ taɪm ən eɪdʒ kʌmz, ən itʃ taɪm ɪts sʌbʒɪkt tə ɡɹeɪɾɝ tʃeɪnʒ, bʌɾ itʃ taɪm ɪts ðə seɪm eɪdʒ.

Wheel of Time, the: Time is a wheel with seven spokes, each spoke an Age. As the Wheel turns, the Ages come and go, each leaving memories that fade to legend, then to myth, and are forgotten by the time that Age comes again. The Pattern of an Age is slightly different each time an Age comes, and each time it is subject to greater change, but each time it is the same Age.

waɪɾ ədʒɑsi ədʒɑ.

White Ajah:See Ajah.

waɪt taʊɝ: ðə pæləs ə ði æmɪɝlɪn siɾ ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn.

White Tower: The palace of the Amyrlin Seat in Tar Valon.

waɪtkloʊkssi tʃɪlʒɹən ə ðə laɪt.

Whitecloaks:See Children of the Light.

wɪzdəm: ɪn vɪlədʒəz, ə wʊmən tʃoʊzən baɪ ðə wɪmənz sɝkəl tə sɪɾ ɪn ðə sɝkəl fəɹ əɹ nɑlədʒ ə sətʃ θɪŋz əz hilɪŋ ən fɔɹtɛlɪŋ ðə wɛðɝ, əz wɛl əz fəɹ kɑmən ɡʊd sɛns. ə pəzɪʃən ʌv ɡɹeɪt ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi ən əθɔɹəɾi, boʊθ æktʃəwəl ən ɪmplaɪd. ʃiz dʒɛnɝəli kənsɪɾɝd ði ikwəl ə ðə meɪɝ, ən ɪn səm vɪlədʒəz ɪz supɪɹiɝ. ənlaɪk ðə meɪɝ, ʃiz tʃoʊzən fəɹ laɪf, ən ɪts vɛɹi ɹɛɹ fəɹ ə wɪzdəm tə bi ɹimuv fɹəm ɔfəs bɪfɔɹ əɹ dɛθ. ɔlmoʊs tʃɹədɪʃənəli ɪn kɑnflɪkt wɪð ðə meɪɝ. si ɔlsoʊ wɪmənz sɝkəl.

Wisdom: In villages, a woman chosen by the Women's Circle to sit in the Circle for her knowledge of such things as healing and foretelling the weather, as well as for common good sense. A position of great responsibility and authority, both actual and implied. She is generally considered the equal of the Mayor, and in some villages his superior. Unlike the Mayor, she is chosen for life, and it is very rare for a Wisdom to be removed from office before her death. Almost traditionally in conflict with the Mayor. See also Women's Circle.

wɪmənz sɝkəl: ə ɡɹup ʌv wɪmən ɪlɛktəd baɪ ðə wɪmən ʌv ə vɪlədʒ, ɹispɑnsəbəl fəɹ dəsaɪɾɪŋ sətʃ mæɾɝz əz ɑɹ kənsɪɾɝd soʊlli wɪmənz ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi (fɔɹ ɪɡzæmpəl, wən tə plæn ðə kɹɑps ən wən tə hɑɹvəst). ikwəl ɪn əθɔɹəɾi tə ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl, wɪð klɪɹli-dɪlɪnieɪɾɪd laɪnz ən ɛɹiəz ə ɹispɑnsəbɪləɾi. ɔfən əɾ ɑdz wɪð ðə vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl. si ɔlsoʊ vɪlədʒ kaʊnsəl.

Women's Circle: A group of women elected by the women of a village, responsible for deciding such matters as are considered solely women's responsibility (for example, when to plant the crops and when to harvest). Equal in authority to the Village Council, with clearly-delineated lines and areas of responsibility. Often at odds with the Village Council. See also Village Council.

The Great Hunt Book Two of The Wheel of Time In the Shadow The man who called himself Bors, at least in this place, sneered at the low murmuring that rolled around the vaulted chamber like the soft gabble of geese. His grimace was hidden by the black silk mask that covered his face, though, just like the masks that covered the hundred other faces in the chamber. A hundred black masks, and a hundred pairs of eyes trying to see what lay behind them.

ɪf wʌn dɪd nɑt lʊk tu kloʊsli, ðə hjudʒ ɹum cʊɾə bɪn ɪn ə pæləs, wɪð ɪts tɔl mɑɹbəl faɪɝpleɪsəz ən ɪts ɡoʊldən læmps hæŋɪŋ fɹəm ðə doʊm silɪŋ, ɪts kʌlɝfəl tæpəstʃɹiz ən ɪntʃɹəkətli pæɾɝnd moʊzeɪɪk flɔɹ. ɪf wʌn dɪd nɑt lʊk tu kloʊsli. ðə faɪɝpleɪsəz wɝ koʊld, fəɹ wʌn θɪŋ. fleɪmz dænst ɑn lɔɡz əz θɪk əz ə mænz lɛɡ, bʌt ɡeɪv noʊ hit. ðə wɔlz bɪhaɪn ðə tæpəstʃɹiz, ðə silɪŋ haɪ əbʌv ðə læmps, wɝ ənʒɹəst stoʊn, ɔlmoʊs blæk. ðəɹ wɝ noʊ wɪndoʊz, ən oʊnli tu dɔɹweɪz, wʌn əɾ iðɝ ɛn ə ðə ɹum. ɪt wɑz əz ɪf sʌmwʌn hæɾ ɪntɛndəd tə ɡɪv ðə sɛmbləns ʌv ə pæləs ɹɪsɛpʃən tʃeɪmbɝ bʌt hæd nɑt kɛɹɾ ɪnʌf tə bɑðɝ wɪð mɔɹ ðən ði aʊtlaɪn ən ə fju tʌtʃəz fəɹ dɪteɪl.

If one did not look too closely, the huge room could have been in a palace, with its tall marble fireplaces and its golden lamps hanging from the domed ceiling, its colorful tapestries and intricately patterned mosaic floor. If one did not look too closely. The fireplaces were cold, for one thing. Flames danced on logs as thick as a man's leg, but gave no heat. The walls behind the tapestries, the ceiling high above the lamps, were undressed stone, almost black. There were no windows, and only two doorways, one at either end of the room. It was as if someone had intended to give the semblance of a palace reception chamber but had not cared enough to bother with more than the outline and a few touches for detail.

wɛɹ ðə tʃeɪmbɝ wɑz, ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz dɪd nɑt noʊ, nɔɹ dɪɾ i θɪŋk ɛni ʌv ði ʌðɝz nu. hi dɪd nɑt laɪk tə θɪŋk əbaʊt wɛɹ ɪt maɪt bi. ɪt wɑz ɪnʌf ðəɾ i hæd bɪn sʌmənd. hi dɪd nɑt laɪk tə θɪŋk əbaʊt ðæt, iðɝ, bʌt fəɹ sətʃ ə sʌmənz, ivən i keɪm.

Where the chamber was, the man who called himself Bors did not know, nor did he think any of the others knew. He did not like to think about where it might be. It was enough that he had been summoned. He did not like to think about that, either, but for such a summons, even he came.

hi ʃɪftəɾ ɪz kloʊk, θæŋkfəl ðət ðə faɪɝz wɝ koʊld, ɛls ɪt wʊɾə bɪn tu hɑt fəɹ ðə blæk wʊl dʒɹeɪpɪŋ ɪm tə ðə flɔɹ. ɔl ɪz kloʊðz wɝ blæk. ðə bʌlki foʊlz ə ðə kloʊk hɪd ðə stup i juz tə dɪsɡaɪz ɪz haɪt, ən bɹɛd kənfjuʒən əz tə wɛðɝ i wɑz θɪn əɹ θɪk. hi wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn ðəɹ ɛnvɛləpt ɪn ə teɪlɝz spæn ə klɔθ.

He shifted his cloak, thankful that the fires were cold, else it would have been too hot for the black wool draping him to the floor. All his clothes were black. The bulky folds of the cloak hid the stoop he used to disguise his height, and bred confusion as to whether he was thin or thick. He was not the only one there enveloped in a tailor's span of cloth.

saɪlənli hi wɑtʃt ɪz kəmpænjənz. peɪʃəns hæd mɑɹk mʌtʃ ə hɪz laɪf. ɔlweɪz, ɪf i weɪɾəd ən wɑtʃt lɔŋ ɪnʌf, sʌmwʌn meɪɾ ə mɪsteɪk. moʊst ə ðə mɛn ən wɪmən hɪɹ maɪɾ əv hæd ðə seɪm fəlɑsəfi; ðeɪ wɑtʃt, ən lɪsən saɪlənli tə ðoʊz u hæd tə spik. səm pipəl kəd nɑt bɛɹ weɪɾɪŋ, əɹ saɪləns, ən soʊ ɡeɪv əweɪ mɔɹ ðən ðeɪ nu.

Silently he watched his companions. Patience had marked much of his life. Always, if he waited and watched long enough, someone made a mistake. Most of the men and women here might have had the same philosophy; they watched, and listened silently to those who had to speak. Some people could not bear waiting, or silence, and so gave away more than they knew.

sɝvəns sɝkjəleɪɾəd θɹu ðə ɡɛsts, slɛndɝ, ɡoʊldən-hɛɹd juðz pɹɑfɝɪŋ waɪn wɪð ə baʊ ən ə wɝdləs smaɪl. jʌŋ mɛn ən jʌŋ wɪmən əlaɪk, ðeɪ wɔɹ taɪt waɪt bɹitʃɪz ən floʊɪŋ waɪt ʃɝts. ən meɪl ən fimeɪl əlaɪk, ðeɪ muvd wɪð dɪstɝbɪŋ ɡɹeɪs. itʃ lʊk mɔɹ ðən ə mɪɹɝ ɪmədʒ ə ði ʌðɝz, ðə bɔɪz əz hænsəm əz ðə ɡɝlz wɝ bjuɾəfəl. hi daʊɾɪd i kəd dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃ wʌn fɹəm ənʌðɝ, ən i hæɾ ən aɪ ən ə mɛmɹi fəɹ feɪsəz.

Servants circulated through the guests, slender, golden-haired youths proffering wine with a bow and a wordless smile. Young men and young women alike, they wore tight white breeches and flowing white shirts. And male and female alike, they moved with disturbing grace. Each looked more than a mirror image of the others, the boys as handsome as the girls were beautiful. He doubted he could distinguish one from another, and he had an eye and a memory for faces.

ə smaɪlɪŋ, waɪt-klæd ɡɝl ɔfɝɾ əɹ tʃɹeɪ ʌv kɹɪstəl ɡoʊbləts tə hɪm. hi tʊk wʌn wɪð noʊ ɪntɛntʃən ə dʒɹɪŋkɪŋ; ɪt maɪɾ əpɪɹ əntʃɹʌstɪŋ - əɹ wɝs, ən iðɝ kəd bi dɛdli hɪɹ - ɪf i ɹəfjuzd ɔltəɡɛðɝ, bʌɾ ɛniθɪŋ kəd bi slɪpt ɪndə ə dʒɹɪŋk. ʃʊɹli səm əmʌŋ ɪz kəmpænjənz wəɾ əv noʊ əbdʒɛkʃənz tə siɪŋ ðə nʌmbɝ ə ðɛɹ ɹaɪvəlz fəɹ paʊɝ dwɪndəl, humɛvɝ ði ənlʌki wʌnz hæpən tə bi.

A smiling, white-clad girl offered her tray of crystal goblets to him. He took one with no intention of drinking; it might appear untrusting - or worse, and either could be deadly here - if he refused altogether, but anything could be slipped into a drink. Surely some among his companions would have no objections to seeing the number of their rivals for power dwindle, whomever the unlucky ones happened to be.

aɪdli hi wʌndɝd wɛðɝ ðə sɝvəns wəɾ əv tə bi dɪspoʊzd ʌv æftɝ ðɪs miɾɪŋ. sɝvəns hɪɹ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. əz ðə sɝvɪŋ ɡɝl stʃɹeɪɾənd fɹəm əɹ baʊ, hɪz aɪ kɑt hɝz əbʌv ðət swit smaɪl. blæŋk aɪz. ɛmpti aɪz. ə dɑlz aɪz. aɪz mɔɹ dɛd ðən dɛθ.

Idly he wondered whether the servants would have to be disposed of after this meeting. Servants hear everything. As the serving girl straightened from her bow, his eye caught hers above that sweet smile. Blank eyes. Empty eyes. A doll's eyes. Eyes more dead than death.

hi ʃɪvɝɾ əz ʃi muvd ɡɹeɪsfəli əweɪ, ən ɹeɪz ðə ɡɑblət tə hɪz lɪps bɪfɔɹ i kɑt hɪmsɛlf. ɪt wɑz nɑt wʌt hæd bɪn dʌn tə ðə ɡɝl ðət tʃɪl hɪm. ɹæðɝ, ɛvɹi taɪm i θɔɾ i dɪtɛktəɾ ə wiknəs ɪn ðoʊz i naʊ sɝvd, hi faʊn hɪmsɛlf pɹɪsiɾɪd, ðə səpoʊzd wiknəs kʌɾ aʊt wɪð ə ɹuθləs pɹisɪʒən ðət lɛft ɪm əmeɪzd. ən wɝid. ðə fɝst ɹul ə hɪz laɪf hæɾ ɔlweɪz bɪn tə sɝtʃ fəɹ wiknəs, fəɹ ɛvɹi wiknəs wɑz ə tʃɪŋk wɛɹ i kəd pɹoʊb ən pɹaɪ ən ɪnfluəns. ɪf ɪz kɝən mæstɝz, hɪz mæstɝz fəɹ ðə moʊmənt, hæd noʊ wiknəs. . . .

He shivered as she moved gracefully away, and raised the goblet to his lips before he caught himself. It was not what had been done to the girl that chilled him. Rather, every time he thought he detected a weakness in those he now served, he found himself preceded, the supposed weakness cut out with a ruthless precision that left him amazed. And worried. The first rule of his life had always been to search for weakness, for every weakness was a chink where he could probe and pry and influence. If his current masters, his masters for the moment, had no weakness. . . .

fɹaʊnɪŋ bɪhaɪn ɪz mæsk, hi stʌɾid ɪz kəmpænjənz. ət lis ðəɹ wɑz plɛnti ʌv wiknəs ðɛɹ. ðɛɹ nɝvəsnəs bɪtʃɹeɪd ðɛm, ivən ðoʊz u hæd sɛns ɪnʌf tə ɡɑɹd ðɛɹ tʌŋz. ə stɪfnəs ɪn ðə weɪ ðɪs wʌn hɛl hɪmsɛlf, ə dʒɝkənəs ɪn ðə weɪ ðət wʌn hændəld əɹ skɝts.

Frowning behind his mask, he studied his companions. At least there was plenty of weakness there. Their nervousness betrayed them, even those who had sense enough to guard their tongues. A stiffness in the way this one held himself, a jerkiness in the way that one handled her skirts.

ə ɡʊd kɔɹɾɝ ə ðɛm, hi ɛstəmeɪɾəd, hæd nɑt bɑðɝd wɪð dɪsɡaɪz bɪɑn ðə blæk mæsks. ðɛɹ kloʊðz toʊl mʌtʃ. ə wʊmən stændɪŋ bɪfɔɹ ə ɡoʊld-ænd-kɹɪmzən wɔl hæŋɪŋ, spikɪŋ sɔfli tə ə fɪɡjɝ - ɪmpɑsəbəl tə seɪ wɛðɝ ɪt wɝ mæn əɹ wʊmən - kloʊkt ən hʊɾɪd ɪn ɡɹeɪ. ʃi hæɾ ɑbviəsli tʃoʊzən ðə spɑt kəz ðə kʌlɝz ə ðə tæpəstʃɹi sɛɾ ɔf əɹ ɡɑɹb. dʌbli fulɪʃ tə dʒɹɔ ətɛnʃən tə hɝsɛlf, fəɹ əɹ skɑɹlət dʒɹɛs, kʌt loʊ ɪn ðə bɑɾəs tə ʃoʊ tu mʌtʃ flɛʃ ən haɪ ət ðə hɛm tə dɪspleɪ ɡoʊldən slɪpɝz, mɑɹkt əɹ fɹəm ɪljən, ən ə wʊmən ʌv wɛlθ, pɝhæps ivən ə noʊbəl blʌd.

A good quarter of them, he estimated, had not bothered with disguise beyond the black masks. Their clothes told much. A woman standing before a gold-and-crimson wall hanging, speaking softly to a figure - impossible to say whether it were man or woman - cloaked and hooded in gray. She had obviously chosen the spot because the colors of the tapestry set off her garb. Doubly foolish to draw attention to herself, for her scarlet dress, cut low in the bodice to show too much flesh and high at the hem to display golden slippers, marked her from Illian, and a woman of wealth, perhaps even of noble blood.

nɑt fɑɹ bɪɑn ði ɪliɑnɝ, ənʌðɝ wʊmən stʊd, əloʊn ən ædmɝəbli saɪlənt. wɪð ə swɑnz nɛk ən lʌstʃɹəs blæk hɛɹ fɔlɪŋ ɪn weɪvz bɪloʊ hɝ weɪst, ʃi kɛpt əɹ bæk tə ðə stoʊn wɔl, əbzɝvɪŋ ɛvɹiθɪŋ. noʊ nɝvəsnəs ðɛɹ, oʊnli sɝin sɛlf-pəzɛʃən. vɛɹi ædmɝəbəl, ðæt, bʌɾ əɹ kɑpɝi skɪn ən əɹ kɹimi, haɪ-nɛkt ɡaʊn - livɪŋ nʌθɪŋ bʌðɝ hænz ənkʌvɝd, jɛt klɪŋɪŋ ən oʊnli dʒʌs bɛɹli oʊpeɪk, soʊ ðəɾ ɪt hɪntəɾ əɾ ɛvɹiθɪŋ ən ɹɪvil nʌθɪŋ - mɑɹkt əɹ dʒʌst əz klɪɹli ʌv ðə fɝs blʌɾ ʌv ɑɹæd dumən. ən ənlɛs ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz mɪst ɪz ɡɛs ɪntaɪɝli, ðə waɪd ɡoʊldən bɹeɪsləɾ ɑn əɹ lɛft ɹɪs bɔɹ əɹ haʊs sɪmbəlz. ðeɪ wəd bi fəɹ əɹ oʊn haʊs; noʊ dəmɑni blʌdbɔɹn wəd bɛn əɹ stɪf pɹaɪɾ ɪnʌf tə wɛɹ ðə sɪɡəlz ʌv ənʌðɝ haʊs. wɝs ðən fulɪʃnəs.

Not far beyond the Illianer, another woman stood, alone and admirably silent. With a swan's neck and lustrous black hair falling in waves below her waist, she kept her back to the stone wall, observing everything. No nervousness there, only serene self-possession. Very admirable, that, but her coppery skin and her creamy, high-necked gown - leaving nothing buther hands uncovered, yet clinging and only just barely opaque, so that it hinted at everything and revealed nothing - marked her just as clearly of the first blood of Arad Doman. And unless the man who called himself Bors missed his guess entirely, the wide golden bracelet on her left wrist bore her House symbols. They would be for her own House; no Domani bloodborn would bend her stiff pride enough to wear the sigils of another House. Worse than foolishness.

ə mæn ɪn ə haɪ-kɑlɝd, skaɪ-blu ʃaɪnɝən koʊt pæst ɪm wɪð ə wɛɹi, hɛd-tə-toʊ ɡlæns θɹu ði aɪhoʊlz ə hɪz mæsk. ðə mænz kæɹɪdʒ neɪmd ɪm soʊlʒɝ; ðə sɛɾ ə hɪz ʃoʊldɝz, ðə weɪ hɪz ɡeɪz nɛvɝ ɹɛstəɾ ɪn wʌn pleɪs fəɹ lɔŋ, ən ðə weɪ hɪz hæn simd ɹɛɾi tə dɑɹt fəɹ ə sɔɹd ðət wɑz nɑt ðɛɹ, ɔl pɹoʊkleɪmd ɪt. ðə ʃaɪnɝən weɪstəd lɪɾəl taɪm ɑn ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz; stupt ʃoʊldɝz ən ə bɛn bæk hɛl noʊ θɹɛt.

A man in a high-collared, sky-blue Shienaran coat passed him with a wary, head-to-toe glance through the eyeholes of his mask. The man's carriage named him soldier; the set of his shoulders, the way his gaze never rested in one place for long, and the way his hand seemed ready to dart for a sword that was not there, all proclaimed it. The Shienaran wasted little time on the man who called himself Bors; stooped shoulders and a bent back held no threat.

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz snɔɹɾɪd əz ðə ʃaɪnɝən muvd ɑn, ɹaɪt hæn klɛntʃɪŋ ən aɪz ɔlɹɛɾi stʌɾiɪŋ ɛlswɛɹ fəɹ deɪnʒɝ. hi kəd ɹiɾ əm ɔl, tə klæs ən kʌntʃɹi. mɝtʃən ən wɔɹiɝ, kɑmənɝ ən noʊbəl. fɹəm kændɝ ən kɛɹhin, sɑldɑiə ən ɡildən. fɹəm ɛvɹi neɪʃən ən nɪɹli ɛvɹi pipəl. hɪz noʊz ɹɪŋkəld ɪn sʌɾən dɪsɡʌst. ivən ə tɪŋkɝ, ɪn bɹaɪt ɡɹin bɹitʃɪz ən ə vɪɹələn jɛloʊ koʊt. wi kən də wɪθaʊt ðoʊz kʌm ðə deɪ.

The man who called himself Bors snorted as the Shienaran moved on, right hand clenching and eyes already studying elsewhere for danger. He could read them all, to class and country. Merchant and warrior, commoner and noble. From Kandor and Cairhien, Saldaea and Ghealdan. From every nation and nearly every people. His nose wrinkled in sudden disgust. Even a Tinker, in bright green breeches and a virulent yellow coat. We can do without those come the Day.

ðə dɪsɡaɪzd wʌnz wɝ noʊ bɛɾɝ, mɛni ʌv ðɛm, kloʊkt ən ʃɹaʊɾɪd əz ðeɪ wɝ. hi kɑt saɪt, ʌndɝ ði ɛdʒ ʌv wʌn dɑɹk ɹoʊb, ʌv ðə sɪlvɝ-wɝk buts ʌv ə haɪ lɔɹɾ ə tiɹ, ən ʌndɝ ənʌðɝ ə ɡlɪmps ʌv ɡoʊldən laɪən-hɛd spɝz, wɔɹn oʊnli baɪ haɪ ɔfəsɝz ɪn ði ændɔɝən kwinz ɡɑɹdz. ə slɛndɝ fɛloʊ - slɛndɝ ivən ɪn ə flɔɹ-dʒɹæɡɪŋ blæk ɹoʊb ən ən ənɑnəməs ɡɹeɪ kloʊk kɑt wɪð ə pleɪn sɪlvɝ pɪn - wɑtʃt fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz ə hɪz dip kaʊl. hi kəd bi ɛniwʌn, fɹəm ɛniwɛɹ . . . ɪksɛp fəɹ ðə sɪks-pɔɪntəd stɑɹ tætuɾ ɑn ðə wɛb bɪtwin θʌm ən fɔɹfɪŋɡɝ ə hɪz ɹaɪt hænd. wʌn ə ðə si foʊk ðɛn, ən ə lʊk əɾ ɪz lɛf hænd wəd ʃoʊ ðə mɑɹks ə hɪz klæn ən laɪn. ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz dɪd nɑt bɑðɝ tə tʃɹaɪ.

The disguised ones were no better, many of them, cloaked and shrouded as they were. He caught sight, under the edge of one dark robe, of the silver-worked boots of a High Lord of Tear, and under another a glimpse of golden lion-head spurs, worn only by high officers in the Andoran Queen's Guards. A slender fellow - slender even in a floor-dragging black robe and an anonymous gray cloak caught with a plain silver pin - watched from the shadows of his deep cowl. He could be anyone, from anywhere . . . except for the six-pointed star tattooed on the web between thumb and forefinger of his right hand. One of the Sea Folk then, and a look at his left hand would show the marks of his clan and line. The man who called himself Bors did not bother to try.

sʌɾənli hɪz aɪz nɛɹoʊd, fɪksɪŋ ɑn ə wʊmən ɛnvɛləpt ɪn blæk tɪl nʌθɪŋ ʃoʊd bʌɾ əɹ fɪŋɡɝz. ɑn əɹ ɹaɪt hæn ɹɛstəɾ ə ɡoʊld ɹɪŋ ɪn ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə sɝpən iɾɪŋ ɪts oʊn teɪl. ɛɛs sədaɪ, əɹ ət list ə wʊmən tʃɹeɪn ɪn tɑɹ vəlɑn baɪ ɛɛs sədaɪ. nʌn ɛls wəd wɛɹ ðət ɹɪŋ. iðɝ weɪ meɪd noʊ dɪfɝəns tə hɪm. hi lʊkt əweɪ bɪfɔɹ ʃi kəd noʊɾəs ɪz wɑtʃɪŋ, ən ɔlmoʊst ɪmiɾiətli hi spɑɾəd ənʌðɝ wʊmən swɑð fɹəm hɛd tə toʊ ɪn blæk ən wɛɹɪŋ ə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ. ðə tu wɪtʃəz ɡeɪv noʊ saɪn ðət ðeɪ nu itʃ ʌðɝ. ɪn ðə waɪt taʊɝ ðeɪ sæt laɪk spaɪɾɝz ɪn ðə mɪɾəl ʌv ə wɛb, pʊlɪŋ ðə stʃɹɪŋz ðət meɪd kɪŋz ən kwinz dæns, mɛɾəlɪŋ. kɝs əm ɔl tə dɛθ ɪtɝnəl! hi ɹilaɪz ðəɾ i wɑz ɡɹaɪndɪŋ ɪz tiθ. ɪf nʌmbɝz mʌs dwɪndəl - ən ðeɪ mʌst, bɪfɔɹ ðə deɪ - ðəɹ wɝ səm u wəd bi mɪst ivən lɛs ðən tɪŋkɝz.

Suddenly his eyes narrowed, fixing on a woman enveloped in black till nothing showed but her fingers. On her right hand rested a gold ring in the shape of a serpent eating its own tail. Aes Sedai, or at least a woman trained in Tar Valon by Aes Sedai. None else would wear that ring. Either way made no difference to him. He looked away before she could notice his watching, and almost immediately he spotted another woman swathed from head to toe in black and wearing a Great Serpent ring. The two witches gave no sign that they knew each other. In the White Tower they sat like spiders in the middle of a web, pulling the strings that made kings and queens dance, meddling. Curse them all to death eternal! He realized that he was grinding his teeth. If numbers must dwindle - and they must, before the Day - there were some who would be missed even less than Tinkers.

ə tʃaɪm saʊndəd, ə sɪŋɡəl, ʃɪvɝɪŋ noʊt ðət keɪm fɹəm ɛvɹiwɛɹ ət wʌns ən kʌɾ ɔf ɔl ʌðɝ saʊnz laɪk ə naɪf.

A chime sounded, a single, shivering note that came from everywhere at once and cut off all other sounds like a knife.

ðə tɔl dɔɹz ət ðə fɑɹ ɛn ə ðə tʃeɪmbɝ swʌŋ oʊpən, ən tu tʃɹɑləks stɛpt ɪndə ðə ɹum, spaɪks dɛkɝeɪɾɪŋ ðə blæk meɪl ðət hʌŋ tə ðɛɹ niz. ɛvɹiwʌn ʃaɪd bæk. ivən ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz.

The tall doors at the far end of the chamber swung open, and two Trollocs stepped into the room, spikes decorating the black mail that hung to their knees. Everyone shied back. Even the man who called himself Bors.

hɛɾ ən ʃoʊldɝz tɔlɝ ðən ðə tɔlɪs mæn ðɛɹ, ðeɪ wɝ ə stʌmək-tɝnɪŋ blɛn ə mæn ən ænəməl, hjumən feɪsəz twɪstəɾ ən ɔltɝd. wʌn hæɾ ə hɛvi, pɔɪntəd bik wɛɹ ɪz maʊθ ən noʊz ʃəɾ əv bɪn, ən fɛðɝz kʌvɝɾ ɪz hɛɾ ɪnstɛɾ ə hɛɹ. ði ʌðɝ wɔkt ɑn hʊvz, hɪz feɪs pʊʃt aʊɾ ɪn ə hɛɹi mʌzəl, ən ɡoʊt hɔɹnz stʌk ʌp əbʌv ɪz ɪɹz.

Head and shoulders taller than the tallest man there, they were a stomach-turning blend of man and animal, human faces twisted and altered. One had a heavy, pointed beak where his mouth and nose should have been, and feathers covered his head instead of hair. The other walked on hooves, his face pushed out in a hairy muzzle, and goat horns stuck up above his ears.

ɪɡnɔɹɪŋ ðə hjumənz, ðə tʃɹɑləks tɝn bæk təwɔɹd ðə dɔɹ ən baʊd, sɝvəl ən kɹɪŋɪŋ. ðə fɛðɝz ɑn ðə wʌn lɪftəɾ ɪn ə taɪt kɹɛst.

Ignoring the humans, the Trollocs turned back toward the door and bowed, servile and cringing. The feathers on the one lifted in a tight crest.

eɪ mɹdʒɹɑl stɛp bɪtwin ðɛm, ən ðeɪ fɛl tə ðɛɹ niz. ɪt wɑz ɡɑɹbd ɪn blæk ðət meɪd ðə tʃɹɑləks' meɪl ən ðə hjumənz' mæsks sim bɹaɪt, ɡɑɹməns ðət hʌŋ stɪl, wɪθaʊɾ ə ɹɪpəl, əz ɪt muvd wɪð ə vaɪpɝz ɡɹeɪs.

A Myrddraal stepped between them, and they fell to their knees. It was garbed in black that made the Trollocs' mail and the humans' masks seem bright, garments that hung still, without a ripple, as it moved with a viper's grace.

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz fɛlt ɪz lɪps dʒɹɔɪŋ bæk oʊvɝ ɪz tiθ, hæf snɑɹl ən hæf, hi wɑz ʃeɪm tə ədmɪɾ ivən tə hɪmsɛlf, fɪɹ. ɪt hæɾ ɪts feɪs ənkʌvɝd. ɪts peɪsti peɪl feɪs, ə mænz feɪs, bʌɾ aɪləs əz ən ɛɡ, laɪk ə mæɡəɾ ɪn ə ɡɹeɪv.

The man who called himself Bors felt his lips drawing back over his teeth, half snarl and half, he was shamed to admit even to himself, fear. It had its face uncovered. Its pasty pale face, a man's face, but eyeless as an egg, like a maggot in a grave.

ðə smuð waɪt feɪs swɪvəld, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ əm ɔl wʌn baɪ wʌn, ɪt simd. ə vɪzəbəl ʃɪvɝ ɹæn θɹu ðɛm ʌndɝ ðəɾ aɪləs lʊk. θɪn, blʌdləs lɪps kwɝkt ɪn wʌt maɪɾ ɔlmoʊst əv bɪn ə smaɪl æz, wʌn baɪ wʌn, ðə mæskt wʌnz tʃɹaɪd tə pɹɛs bæk ɪndə ðə kɹaʊd, mɪlɪŋ tə əvɔɪd ðət ɡeɪz. ðə mɹdʒɹɑlz lʊk ʃeɪpt əm ɪndə ə sɛmɪsɝkəl feɪsɪŋ ðə dɔɹ.

The smooth white face swiveled, regarding them all one by one, it seemed. A visible shiver ran through them under that eyeless look. Thin, bloodless lips quirked in what might almost have been a smile as, one by one, the masked ones tried to press back into the crowd, milling to avoid that gaze. The Myrddraal's look shaped them into a semicircle facing the door.

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz swɑloʊd. ðəɹ wɪl kʌm ə deɪ, hæfmən. wən ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk kʌmz əɡɛn, hɪl tʃuz ɪz nu dʒɹɛdlɔɹdz, ən jəl kaʊɝ bɪfɔɹ ðɛm. jəl kaʊɝ bɪfɔɹ mɛn. bɪfɔɹ mi! waɪ dʌzn ɪt spik? stɑp stɛɹɪŋ ət mi, ən spik!

The man who called himself Bors swallowed. There will come a day, Halfman. When the Great Lord of the Dark comes again, he will choose his new Dreadlords, and you will cower before them. You will cower before men. Before me! Why doesn't it speak? Stop staring at me, and speak!

"jɔɹ mæstɝ kʌmz." ðə mɹdʒɹɑlz vɔɪs ɹæsp laɪk ə dʒɹaɪ sneɪkɛskɪn kɹʌmbəlɪŋ. "tə jəɹ bɛliz, wɝmz! ɡɹɑvəl, lɛst ɪz bɹɪljəns blaɪn ən bɝn ju!"

"Your Master comes." The Myrddraal's voice rasped like a dry snakeskin crumbling. "To your bellies, worms! Grovel, lest his brilliance blind and burn you!"

ɹeɪdʒ fɪl ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz, ət ðə toʊn əz mʌtʃ əz ðə wɝdz, bʌt ðən ði ɛɹ əbʌv ðə hæfmən ʃɪmɝd, ən ði ɪmpɔɹt dʒɹoʊv hoʊm. ɪt kæn bi! ɪt kænt . . . ! ðə tʃɹɑləks wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɑn ðɛɹ bɛliz, ɹaɪðɪŋ əz ɪf ðeɪ wɑntəd tə bɝoʊ ɪndə ðə flɔɹ.

Rage filled the man who called himself Bors, at the tone as much as the words, but then the air above the Halfman shimmered, and the import drove home. It can't be! It can't . . . ! The Trollocs were already on their bellies, writhing as if they wanted to burrow into the floor.

wɪθaʊt weɪɾɪŋ tə si ɪf ɛniwʌn ɛls muvd, ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz dʒɹɑp feɪsdaʊn, ɡɹʌntɪŋ əz i bɹuz hɪmsɛlf ɑn ðə stoʊn. wɝdz spɹæŋ tə hɪz lɪps laɪk ə tʃɑɹm əɡɛns deɪnʒɝ - ðeɪ wɝ ə tʃɑɹm, ðoʊ ə θɪn ɹiɾ əɡɛnst wʌɾ i fɪɹd - ən i hɝɾ ə hʌnʒɹəd ʌðɝ vɔɪsəz, bɹɛθi wɪð fɪɹ, spikɪŋ ðə seɪm əɡɛns ðə flɔɹ.

Without waiting to see if anyone else moved, the man who called himself Bors dropped facedown, grunting as he bruised himself on the stone. Words sprang to his lips like a charm against danger - they were a charm, though a thin reed against what he feared - and he heard a hundred other voices, breathy with fear, speaking the same against the floor.

"ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk ɪz maɪ mæstɝ, ən moʊs hɑɹɾəli də aɪ sɝv ɪm tə ðə læst ʃɹɛɾ ə maɪ vɛɹi soʊl." ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪn ə vɔɪs tʃæɾɝd wɪð fɪɹ. ðə dɑɹk wʌn ən ɔl ðə fɔɹseɪkən ɑɹ baʊnd. . . . ʃɪvɝɪŋ, hi fɔɹst ɪt tə saɪləns. hi hæɾ əbændən ðət vɔɪs lɔŋ sɪns. "loʊ, maɪ mæstɝ ɪz dɛθs mæstɝ. æskɪŋ nʌθɪŋ də aɪ sɝv əɡɛns ðə deɪ ʌv ɪz kʌmɪŋ, jɛt də aɪ sɝv ɪn ðə ʃʊɹ ən sɝɾən hoʊp ə laɪf ɛvɝlæstɪŋ." . . . baʊn ɪn ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl, baʊn baɪ ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ət ðə moʊmən ə kɹieɪʃən. noʊ, aɪ sɝv ə dɪfɹən mæstɝ naʊ. "ʃʊɹli ðə feɪθfəl ʃæl bi ɪɡzɔltɪɾ ɪn ðə lænd, ɪɡzɔltɪɾ əbʌv ði ʌnbəlivɝz, ɪɡzɔltɪɾ əbʌv θɹoʊnz, jɛt də aɪ sɝv hʌmbli əɡɛns ðə deɪ ʌv ɪz ɹɪtɝn." ðə hæn ə ðə kɹieɪɾɝ ʃɛltɝz əs ɔl, ən ðə laɪt pɹətɛks əs fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊ. noʊ, noʊ! ə dɪfɹən mæstɝ. "swɪf kʌm ðə deɪ ʌv ɹɪtɝn. swɪf kʌm ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk tə ɡaɪɾ əs ən ɹul ðə wɝl fɝɛvɝ ən ɛvɝ."

"The Great Lord of the Dark is my Master, and most heartily do I serve him to the last shred of my very soul." In the back of his mind a voice chattered with fear. The Dark One and all the Forsaken are bound. . . . Shivering, he forced it to silence. He had abandoned that voice long since. "Lo, my Master is death's Master. Asking nothing do I serve against the Day of his coming, yet do I serve in the sure and certain hope of life everlasting." . . . bound in Shayol Ghul, bound by the Creator at the moment of creation. No, I serve a different master now. "Surely the faithful shall be exalted in the land, exalted above the unbelievers, exalted above thrones, yet do I serve humbly against the Day of his Return." The hand of the Creator shelters us all, and the Light protects us from the Shadow. No, no! A different master. "Swift come the Day of Return. Swift come the Great Lord of the Dark to guide us and rule the world forever and ever."

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz fɪnɪʃt ðə kɹid pæntɪŋ, əz ɪf i hæd ɹʌn tɛn maɪlz. ðə ɹæsp ə bɹɛθ ɔl ɝaʊn toʊld ɪm i wɑz nɑt ði oʊnli wʌn.

The man who called himself Bors finished the creed panting, as if he had run ten miles. The rasp of breath all around told him he was not the only one.

"ɹaɪz. ɔl ə ju, ɹaɪz."

"Rise. All of you, rise."

ðə mɛləfls vɔɪs tʊk ɪm baɪ sɝpɹaɪz. ʃʊɹli nʌn ə hɪz kəmpænjənz, laɪɪŋ ɑn ðɛɹ bɛliz wɪð ðɛɹ mæsk feɪsəz pɹɛs tə ðə moʊzeɪɪk taɪlz, wəɾ əv spoʊkən, bʌɾ ɪt wɑz nɑt ðə vɔɪs i ɪkspɛktəd fɹʌm. . . . kɔʃəsli, hi ɹeɪzd ɪz hɛɾ ɪnʌf tə si wɪð wʌn aɪ.

The mellifluous voice took him by surprise. Surely none of his companions, lying on their bellies with their masked faces pressed to the mosaic tiles, would have spoken, but it was not the voice he expected from. . . . Cautiously, he raised his head enough to see with one eye.

ðə fɪɡjɝ ʌv ə mæn floʊɾəd ɪn ði ɛɹ əbʌv ðə mɹdʒɹɑl, ðə hɛm ə hɪz blʌd ɹɛd ɹoʊb hæŋɪŋ ə spæn oʊvɝ ðə hæfmənz hɛd. mæskt ɪn blʌd ɹɛd, tu. wəd ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk əpɪɹ tə ðɛm əz ə mæn? ən mæskt, bɪsaɪdz? jɛt ðə mɹdʒɹɑl, ɪts vɛɹi ɡeɪz fɪɹ, tʃɹɛmbəld ən ɔlmoʊs kaʊɝd wɛɹ ɪt stʊɾ ɪn ðə fɪɡjɝz ʃædoʊ. ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz ɡɹæsp fəɹ ən ænsɝ ɪz maɪn kəd kənteɪn wɪθaʊt splɪɾɪŋ. wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən, pɝhæps.

The figure of a man floated in the air above the Myrddraal, the hem of his blood red robe hanging a span over the Halfman's head. Masked in blood red, too. Would the Great Lord of the Dark appear to them as a man? And masked, besides? Yet the Myrddraal, its very gaze fear, trembled and almost cowered where it stood in the figure's shadow. The man who called himself Bors grasped for an answer his mind could contain without splitting. One of the Forsaken, perhaps.

ðət θɔt wɑz oʊnli ə lɪɾəl lɛs peɪnfəl. ivən soʊ, ɪt mɛn ðə deɪ ʌv ðə dɑɹk wʌnz ɹɪtɝn mʌs bi kloʊs ət hæn ɪf wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən wɑz fɹi. ðə fɔɹseɪkən, θɝtin ə ðə moʊs paʊɝfəl wildɝz ə ðə wʌn paʊɝ ɪn ən eɪdʒ fɪld wɪð paʊɝfəl wildɝz, hæd bɪn sild ʌp ɪn ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl əlɔŋ wɪð ðə dɑɹk wʌn, sild əweɪ fɹəm ðə wɝld ə mɛn baɪ ðə dʒɹæɡən ən ðə hʌnʒɹəd kəmpænjənz. ən ðə bækbləst ə ðət silɪŋ hæd teɪntɪd ðə meɪl hæf ə ðə tʃɹu sɔɹs; ən ɔl ðə meɪl ɛɛs sədaɪ, ðoʊz kɝst wildɝz ə ðə paʊɝ, wɛn mæɾ ən bɹoʊk ðə wɝld, tɔɹ ɪɾ əpɑɹt laɪk ə pɑɾɝi boʊl smæʃt ɑn ɹɑks, ɛndɪŋ ði eɪdʒ ə lɛdʒənz bɪfɔɹ ðeɪ daɪd, ɹɑɾɪŋ waɪl ðeɪ stɪl lɪvd. ə fɪɾɪŋ dɛθ fəɹ ɛɛs sədaɪ, tə hɪz maɪnd. tu ɡʊd fəɹ ðɛm. hi ɹɪɡɹɛɾɪd oʊnli ðət ðə wɪmən hæd bɪn spɛɹd.

That thought was only a little less painful. Even so, it meant the Day of the Dark One's return must be close at hand if one of the Forsaken was free. The Forsaken, thirteen of the most powerful wielders of the One Power in an Age filled with powerful wielders, had been sealed up in Shayol Ghul along with the Dark One, sealed away from the world of men by the Dragon and the Hundred Companions. And the backblast of that sealing had tainted the male half of the True Source; and all the male Aes Sedai, those cursed wielders of the Power, went mad and broke the world, tore it apart like a pottery bowl smashed on rocks, ending the Age of Legends before they died, rotting while they still lived. A fitting death for Aes Sedai, to his mind. Too good for them. He regretted only that the women had been spared.

sloʊli, peɪnfəli, hi fɔɹs ðə pænɪk tə ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪnd, kənfaɪn ɪɾ ən hɛld ɪt taɪt ðoʊ ɪt skɹim tə ɡɛɾ aʊt. ɪt wɑz ðə bɛst i kəd du. nʌn ə ðoʊz ɑn ðɛɹ bɛliz hæd ɹɪzən, ən oʊnli ə fju hæɾ ivən dɛɹd ɹeɪz ðɛɹ hɛdz.

Slowly, painfully, he forced the panic to the back of his mind, confined it and held it tight though it screamed to get out. It was the best he could do. None of those on their bellies had risen, and only a few had even dared raise their heads.

"ɹaɪz." ðəɹ wɑz ə snæp ɪn ðə ɹɛd-mæsk fɪɡjɝz vɔɪs ðɪs taɪm. hi dʒɛstʃɝd wɪð boʊθ hænz. "stænd!"

"Rise." There was a snap in the red-masked figure's voice this time. He gestured with both hands. "Stand!"

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz skɹæmbəld ʌp ɔkwɝdli, bʌt hæfweɪ tə hɪz fit, hi hɛzɪteɪɾɪd. ðoʊz dʒɛstʃɝɪŋ hænz wɝ hɔɹəbli bɝnd, kɹɪskɹɔs baɪ blæk fɪʃɝz, ðə ɹɔ flɛʃ bɪtwin əz ɹɛɾ əz ðə fɪɡjɝz ɹoʊbz. wəd ðə dɑɹk wʌn əpɪɹ soʊ? əɹ ivən wʌn ə ðə fɔɹseɪkən? ði aɪhoʊlz ə ðət blʌd ɹɛd mæsk swɛp sloʊli əkɹɔs hɪm, ən i stʃɹeɪɾənd heɪstəli. hi θɔɾ i kəd fil ðə hiɾ ʌv ən oʊpən fɝnəs ɪn ðət ɡeɪz.

The man who called himself Bors scrambled up awkwardly, but halfway to his feet, he hesitated. Those gesturing hands were horribly burned, crisscrossed by black fissures, the raw flesh between as red as the figure's robes. Would the Dark One appear so? Or even one of the Forsaken? The eyeholes of that blood red mask swept slowly across him, and he straightened hastily. He thought he could feel the heat of an open furnace in that gaze.

ði ʌðɝz oʊbeɪd ðə kəmænd wɪð noʊ mɔɹ ɡɹeɪs ən noʊ lɛs fɪɹ ɪn ðɛɹ ɹaɪzɪŋ. wən ɔl wɝ ɑn ðɛɹ fit, ðə floʊɾɪŋ fɪɡjɝ spoʊk.

The others obeyed the command with no more grace and no less fear in their rising. When all were on their feet, the floating figure spoke.

"aɪ hæv bɪn noʊn baɪ mɛni neɪmz, bʌt ðə wʌn baɪ wɪtʃ jə ʃæl noʊ mi ɪz bælzəmən."

"I have been known by many names, but the one by which you shall know me is Ba'alzamon."

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz klæmpt ɪz tiθ tə kip əm fɹəm tʃæɾɝɪŋ. bælzəmən. ɪn ðə tʃɹɑlɑk tʌŋ, ɪt mɛn hɑɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk, ən ivən ʌnbəlivɝz nu ɪt wɑz ðə tʃɹɑlɑk neɪm fəɹ ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk. hi huz neɪm mʌs nɑt bi ʌɾɝd. nɑt ðə tʃɹu neɪm, ʃeɪtɑn, bʌt stɪl fɔɹbɪɾən. əmʌŋ ðoʊz ɡæðɝd hɪɹ, ən ʌðɝz ə ðɛɹ kaɪnd, tə sʌli iðɝ wɪð ə hjumən tʌŋ wɑz blæsfəmi. hɪz bɹɛθ wɪsəl θɹu hɪz nɑstʃɹəlz, ən ɔl ɝaʊn ɪm i kəd hɪɹ ʌðɝz pæntɪŋ bɪhaɪn ðɛɹ mæsks. ðə sɝvəns wɝ ɡɔn, ən ðə tʃɹɑləks əz wɛl, ðoʊ hi hæd nɑt sin əm ɡoʊ.

The man who called himself Bors clamped his teeth to keep them from chattering. Ba'alzamon. In the Trolloc tongue, it meant Heart of the Dark, and even unbelievers knew it was the Trolloc name for the Great Lord of the Dark. He Whose Name Must Not Be Uttered. Not the True Name, Shai'tan, but still forbidden. Among those gathered here, and others of their kind, to sully either with a human tongue was blasphemy. His breath whistled through his nostrils, and all around him he could hear others panting behind their masks. The servants were gone, and the Trollocs as well, though he had not seen them go.

"ðə pleɪs wɛɹ jə stæn laɪz ɪn ðə ʃædoʊ ʌv ʃeɪɑl ɡʌl." mɔɹ ðən wʌn vɔɪs moʊn ət ðæt; ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪz oʊn wɑz nɑɾ əmʌŋ ðɛm. ə tʌtʃ ʌv wʌt maɪɾ ɔlmoʊs bi kɔl mɑkɝi ɛntɝd bælzəmənz vɔɪs əz i spɹɛɾ ɪz ɑɹmz waɪd. "fɪɹ nɑt, fəɹ ðə deɪ ʌv jəɹ mæstɝz ɹaɪzɪŋ əpɑn ðə wɝld ɪz nɪɹ ət hænd. ðə deɪ ʌv ɹɪtɝn dʒɹɔz naɪ. dʌz ɪt nɑt tɛl jə soʊ ðəɾ aɪm hɪɹ, tə bi sin baɪ jə feɪvɝd fju əmʌŋ jəɹ bɹʌðɝz ən sɪstɝz? sun ðə wil ə taɪm wɪl bi bɹoʊkən. sun ðə ɡɹeɪt sɝpənt wɪl daɪ, ən wɪð ðə paʊɝ ə ðət dɛθ, ðə dɛθ ə taɪm ɪtsɛlf, jəɹ mæstɝ wɪl ɹimeɪk ðə wɝld ɪn ɪz oʊn ɪmədʒ fəɹ ðɪs eɪdʒ ən fəɹ ɔl eɪdʒəz tə kʌm. ən ðoʊz u sɝv mi, feɪθfəl ən stɛdfæst, wɪl sɪɾ ət maɪ fiɾ əbʌv ðə stɑɹz ɪn ðə skaɪ ən ɹul ðə wɝld ə mɛn fɝɛvɝ. soʊ hæv aɪ pɹɑməst, ən soʊ ʃæl ɪt bi, wɪθaʊɾ ɛnd. jə ʃæl lɪv ən ɹul fɝɛvɝ."

"The place where you stand lies in the shadow of Shayol Ghul." More than one voice moaned at that; the man who called himself Bors was not sure his own was not among them. A touch of what might almost be called mockery entered Ba'alzamon's voice as he spread his arms wide. "Fear not, for the Day of your Master's rising upon the world is near at hand. The Day of Return draws nigh. Does it not tell you so that I am here, to be seen by you favored few among your brothers and sisters? Soon the Wheel of Time will be broken. Soon the Great Serpent will die, and with the power of that death, the death of Time itself, your Master will remake the world in his own image for this Age and for all Ages to come. And those who serve me, faithful and steadfast, will sit at my feet above the stars in the sky and rule the world of men forever. So have I promised, and so shall it be, without end. You shall live and rule forever."

ə mɝmɝ ʌv æntɪsəpeɪʃən ɹæn θɹu ðə lɪsənɝz, ən səm ivən tʊk ə stɛp fɔɹwɝd, təwɔɹd ðə floʊɾɪŋ, kɹɪmzən ʃeɪp, ðɛɹ aɪz lɪftəd, ɹæptʃɝəs. ivən ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz fɛl ðə pʊl ə ðət pɹɑməs, ðə pɹɑməs fəɹ wɪtʃ i hæd dɛlt əweɪ hɪz soʊl ə hʌnʒɹəd taɪmz oʊvɝ.

A murmur of anticipation ran through the listeners, and some even took a step forward, toward the floating, crimson shape, their eyes lifted, rapturous. Even the man who called himself Bors felt the pull of that promise, the promise for which he had dealt away his soul a hundred times over.

"ðə deɪ ʌv ɹɪtɝn kʌmz kloʊsɝ," bælzəmən sɛd. "bʌt ðəɹ ɪz mʌtʃ jɛt tə du. mʌtʃ tə du."

"The Day of Return comes closer," Ba'alzamon said. "But there is much yet to do. Much to do."

ði ɛɹ tə bælzəmənz lɛft ʃɪmɝɾ ən θɪkənd, ən ðə fɪɡjɝ ʌv ə jʌŋ mæn hʌŋ ðɛɹ, ə lɪɾəl loʊɝ ðən bælzəmən. ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz kəd nɑt dɪsaɪd wɛðɝ ɪt wɑz ə lɪvɪŋ biɪŋ əɹ nɑt. ə kʌntʃɹi læd, baɪ hɪz kloʊðz, wɪð ə laɪɾ ə mɪstʃəf ɪn ɪz bɹaʊn aɪz ən ðə hɪn ʌv ə smaɪl ɑn ɪz lɪps, əz ɪf ɪn mɛmɹi əɹ æntɪsəpeɪʃən ʌv ə pɹæŋk. ðə flɛʃ lʊkt wɔɹm, bʌt ðə tʃɛs dɪd nɑt muv wɪð bɹɛθ, ði aɪz dɪd nɑt blɪŋk.

The air to Ba'alzamon's left shimmered and thickened, and the figure of a young man hung there, a little lower than Ba'alzamon. The man who called himself Bors could not decide whether it was a living being or not. A country lad, by his clothes, with a light of mischief in his brown eyes and the hint of a smile on his lips, as if in memory or anticipation of a prank. The flesh looked warm, but the chest did not move with breath, the eyes did not blink.

ði ɛɹ tə bælzəmənz ɹaɪt weɪvɝɾ əz ɪf wɪð hit, ən ə sɛkən kʌntʃɹi-klæd fɪɡjɝ hʌŋ səspɛndəɾ ə lɪɾəl bɪloʊ bælzəmən. ə kɝli-hɛɹd juθ, əz hɛvəli mʌsəld əz ə blæksmɪθ. ən ən ɑɾəti: ə bæɾəliks hʌŋ əɾ ɪz saɪd, ə ɡɹeɪt, stil hæf-mun bæləns baɪ ə θɪk spaɪk. ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz sʌɾənli lin fɔɹwɝd, ɪntɛn ɑn ən ivən ɡɹeɪɾɝ stʃɹeɪnʒnəs. ə juθ wɪð jɛloʊ aɪz.

The air to Ba'alzamon's right wavered as if with heat, and a second country-clad figure hung suspended a little below Ba'alzamon. A curly-haired youth, as heavily muscled as a blacksmith. And an oddity: a battleaxe hung at his side, a great, steel half-moon balanced by a thick spike. The man who called himself Bors suddenly leaned forward, intent on an even greater strangeness. A youth with yellow eyes.

fəɹ ðə θɝd taɪm ɛɹ səlɪɾəfaɪd ɪndə ðə ʃeɪp ʌv ə jʌŋ mæn, ðɪs taɪm dɝɛkli ʌndɝ bælzəmənz aɪ, ɔlmoʊst əɾ ɪz fit. ə tɔl fɛloʊ, wɪð aɪz naʊ ɡɹeɪ, naʊ ɔlmoʊs blu əz ðə laɪt tʊk ðɛm, ən dɑɹk, ɹɛɾɪʃ hɛɹ. ənʌðɝ vɪlɪdʒɝ, əɹ fɑɹmɝ. ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz ɡæspt. jɛɾ ənʌðɝ θɪŋ aʊɾ ə ði ɔɹɾənɛɹi, ðoʊ hi wʌndɝd waɪ hi ʃəɾ ɪkspɛkt ɛniθɪŋ tə bi ɔɹɾənɛɹi hɪɹ. ə sɔɹd swʌŋ fɹəm ðə fɪɡjɝz bɛlt, ə sɔɹd wɪð ə bɹɑnz hɛɹən ɑn ðə skæbɝɾ ən ənʌðɝ ɪnsɛɾ ɪndə ðə lɔŋ, tu-hændəd hɪlt. ə vɪlədʒ bɔɪ wɪð ə hɛɹən-mɑɹk bleɪd? ɪmpɑsəbəl! wʌt kən ɪt min? ən ə bɔɪ wɪð jɛloʊ aɪz. hi noʊɾəst ðə mɹdʒɹɑl lʊkɪŋ ət ðə fɪɡjɝz, tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ; ən ənlɛs i mɪsdʒʌdʒd ɪntaɪɝli, ɪts tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ wɑz noʊ lɔŋɡɝ fɪɹ, bʌt heɪtʃɹəd.

For the third time air solidified into the shape of a young man, this time directly under Ba'alzamon's eye, almost at his feet. A tall fellow, with eyes now gray, now almost blue as the light took them, and dark, reddish hair. Another villager, or farmer. The man who called himself Bors gasped. Yet another thing out of the ordinary, though he wondered why he should expect anything to be ordinary here. A sword swung from the figure's belt, a sword with a bronze heron on the scabbard and another inset into the long, two-handed hilt. A village boy with a heron-mark blade? Impossible! What can it mean? And a boy with yellow eyes. He noticed the Myrddraal looking at the figures, trembling; and unless he misjudged entirely, its trembling was no longer fear, but hatred.

dɛd saɪləns hæd fɔlən, saɪləns ðət bælzəmən lɛt dipən bɪfɔɹ i spoʊk. "ðɛɹ ɪz naʊ wʌn u wɔks ðə wɝld, wʌn u wɑz ən wɪl bi, bʌɾ ɪz nɑt jɛt, ðə dʒɹæɡən."

Dead silence had fallen, silence that Ba'alzamon let deepen before he spoke. "There is now one who walks the world, one who was and will be, but is not yet, the Dragon."

ə stɑɹɾəld mɝmɝ ɹæn θɹu hɪz lɪsənɝz.

A startled murmur ran through his listeners.

"ðə dʒɹæɡən ɹibɔɹn! wəɹ tə kɪl hɪm, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd?" ðət fɹəm ðə ʃaɪnɝən, hænd ɡɹæspɪŋ iɡɝli əɾ ɪz saɪd wɛɹ ɪz sɔɹd wəd hæŋ.

"The Dragon Reborn! We are to kill him, Great Lord?" That from the Shienaran, hand grasping eagerly at his side where his sword would hang.

"pɝhæps," bælzəmən sɛd sɪmpli. "æn pɝhæps nɑt. pɝhæps i kən bi tɝn tə maɪ juz. sunɝ əɹ leɪɾɝ ɪɾəl bi soʊ, ɪn ðɪs eɪdʒ əɹ ənʌðɝ."

"Perhaps," Ba'alzamon said simply. "And perhaps not. Perhaps he can be turned to my use. Sooner or later it will be so, in this Age or another."

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz blɪŋkt. ɪn ðɪs eɪdʒ əɹ ənʌðɝ? aɪ θɔt ðə deɪ ʌv ɹɪtɝn wɑz nɪɹ. wʌt mæɾɝ tə mi wʌt hæpənz ɪn ənʌðɝ eɪdʒ ɪf aɪ ɡɹoʊ oʊld ən daɪ weɪɾɪŋ ɪn ðɪs wʌn? bʌt bælzəmən wɑz spikɪŋ əɡɛn.

The man who called himself Bors blinked. In this Age or another? I thought the Day of Return was near. What matter to me what happens in another Age if I grow old and die waiting in this one? But Ba'alzamon was speaking again.

"ɔlɹɛɾi ə bɛn ɪz fɔɹmɪŋ ɪn ðə pæɾɝn, wʌn ə mɛni pɔɪns wɛɹ i hu wɪl bɪkʌm ðə dʒɹæɡən meɪ bi tɝn tə maɪ sɝvəs. mʌs bi tɝnd! bɛɾɝ ðəɾ i sɝv mi əlaɪv ðən dɛd, bʌɾ əlaɪv əɹ dɛd, sɝv mi hi mʌst ən wɪl! ðiz θɹi jə mʌs noʊ, fəɹ itʃ ɪz ə θɹɛɾ ɪn ðə pæɾɝn aɪ min tə wiv, ən ɪɾəl bi ʌp tə jə tə si ðət ðeɪ ɑɹ pleɪst əz aɪ kəmænd. stʌɾi ðɛm wɛl, ðət jəl noʊ ðɛm."

"Already a bend is forming in the Pattern, one of many points where he who will become the Dragon may be turned to my service. Must be turned! Better that he serve me alive than dead, but alive or dead, serve me he must and will! These three you must know, for each is a thread in the pattern I mean to weave, and it will be up to you to see that they are placed as I command. Study them well, that you will know them."

əbɹʌpli ɔl saʊnd wɑz ɡɔn. ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz ʃɪftəɾ ənizəli, ən sɔ ʌðɝz duɪŋ ðə seɪm. ɔl bʌt ði ɪliɑnɝ wʊmən, hi ɹilaɪzd. wɪð əɹ hænz spɹɛɾ oʊvɝ əɹ bʊzəm əz ɪf tə haɪd ðə ɹaʊndəd flɛʃ ʃi ɪkspoʊzd, aɪz waɪd, hæf fɹaɪɾənd ən hæf ɛkstæɾɪk, ʃi wɑz nɑɾɪŋ iɡɝli əz ðoʊ tə sʌmwʌn feɪs-tə-feɪs wɪð hɝ. səmtaɪmz ʃi əpɪɹd tə ɡɪv ə ɹɪplaɪ, bʌt ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz hɝd nɑɾ ə wɝd. sʌɾənli ʃi ɑɹtʃt bækwɝdz, tʃɹɛmbəlɪŋ ən ɹaɪzɪŋ ɑn əɹ toʊz. hi kəd nɑt si waɪ ʃi dɪd nɑt fɔl, ənlɛs sʌmθɪŋ ənsin hɛl hɝ. ðɛn, dʒʌst əz əbɹʌpli, ʃi sɛɾəld bæk tə hɝ fiɾ ən nɑɾəd əɡɛn, boʊɪŋ, ʃɪvɝɪŋ. ivən əz ʃi stʃɹeɪɾənd, wʌn ə ðə wɪmən wɛɹɪŋ ə ɡɹeɪt sɝpən ɹɪŋ ɡeɪv ə stɑɹɾ ən bɪɡæn nɑɾɪŋ.

Abruptly all sound was gone. The man who called himself Bors shifted uneasily, and saw others doing the same. All but the Illianer woman, he realized. With her hands spread over her bosom as if to hide the rounded flesh she exposed, eyes wide, half frightened and half ecstatic, she was nodding eagerly as though to someone face-to-face with her. Sometimes she appeared to give a reply, but the man who called himself Bors heard not a word. Suddenly she arched backwards, trembling and rising on her toes. He could not see why she did not fall, unless something unseen held her. Then, just as abruptly, she settled back to her feet and nodded again, bowing, shivering. Even as she straightened, one of the women wearing a Great Serpent ring gave a start and began nodding.

soʊ itʃ ʌv əs hɪɹz ɪz oʊn ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz, ən nʌn hɪɹz ənʌðɝz. ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz mʌɾɝd ɪn fɹəstʃɹeɪʃən. ɪf i nu wʌɾ ivən wʌn ʌðɝ wɑz kəmændəd, hi maɪt bi eɪbəl tə juz ðə nɑlədʒ tə ædvæntɪdʒ, bʌt ðɪs weɪ. . . . ɪmpeɪʃənli hi weɪɾəd fəɹ ɪz tɝn, fɝɡɛɾɪŋ hɪmsɛlf ɪnʌf tə stæn stʃɹeɪt.

So each of us hears his own instructions, and none hears another's. The man who called himself Bors muttered in frustration. If he knew what even one other was commanded, he might be able to use the knowledge to advantage, but this way. . . . Impatiently he waited for his turn, forgetting himself enough to stand straight.

wʌn baɪ wʌn ðə ɡæðɝɪŋ ɹəsiv ðɛɹ ɔɹɾɝz, itʃ wɔld ɪn saɪləns jɛt stɪl ɡɪvɪŋ tæntəlaɪzɪŋ kluz, ɪf oʊnli hi kəd ɹid ðɛm. ðə mæn ə ði æθɑn maɪɹ, ðə si foʊk, stɪfənɪŋ wɪð ɹɪlʌktəns əz i nɑɾəd. ðə ʃaɪnɝən, hɪz stæns bi spikɪŋ kənfjuʒən ivən waɪl i ækwiɛst. ðə sɛkənd wʊmən ə tɑɹ vəlɑn ɡɪvɪŋ ə stɑɹt, əz ə ʃɑk, ən ðə ɡɹeɪ-swɑð fɪɡjɝ huz sɛks i kəd nɑt dətɝmən ʃeɪkɪŋ ɪts hɛd bɪfɔɹ fɔlɪŋ tə ɪts niz ən nɑɾɪŋ vɪɡɝəsli. səm ʌndɝwɛn ðə seɪm kənvʌlʃən əz ði ɪliɑnɝ wʊmən, əz ɪf peɪn ɪtsɛlf lɪftəɾ əm tə toʊ tɪps.

One by one the gathering received their orders, each walled in silence yet still giving tantalizing clues, if only he could read them. The man of the Atha'an Miere, the Sea Folk, stiffening with reluctance as he nodded. The Shienaran, his stance be speaking confusion even while he acquiesced. The second woman of Tar Valon giving a start, as of shock, and the gray-swathed figure whose sex he could not determine shaking its head before falling to its knees and nodding vigorously. Some underwent the same convulsion as the Illianer woman, as if pain itself lifted them to toe tips.

"bɔɹz."

"Bors."

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz dʒɝkt əz ə ɹɛd mæsk fɪld ɪz aɪz. hi kəd stɪl si ðə ɹum, stɪl si ðə floʊɾɪŋ ʃeɪp ə bælzəmən ən ðə θɹi fɪɡjɝz bɪfɔɹ hɪm, bʌɾ ət ðə seɪm taɪm ɔl i kəd si wɑz ðə ɹɛd-mæsk feɪs. dɪzi, hi fɛlt əz ɪf ɪz skʌl wɝ splɪɾɪŋ oʊpən ən ɪz aɪz wɝ biɪŋ pʊʃt aʊɾ ə hɪz hɛd. fəɹ ə moʊmən i θɔɾ i kəd si fleɪmz θɹu ði aɪhoʊlz ə ðə mæsk.

The man who called himself Bors jerked as a red mask filled his eyes. He could still see the room, still see the floating shape of Ba'alzamon and the three figures before him, but at the same time all he could see was the red-masked face. Dizzy, he felt as if his skull were splitting open and his eyes were being pushed out of his head. For a moment he thought he could see flames through the eyeholes of the mask.

"ɑɹ jə feɪθfəl . . . bɔɹz?"

"Are you faithful . . . Bors?"

ðə hɪn ə mɑkɪŋ ɪn ðə neɪm sɛn ə tʃɪl daʊn ɪz bækboʊn. "aɪ æm feɪθfəl, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd. aɪ kænɑt haɪd fɹəm ju." aɪm feɪθfəl! aɪ swɛɹ ɪt!

The hint of mocking in the name sent a chill down his backbone. "I am faithful, Great Lord. I cannot hide from you." I am faithful! I swear it!

"noʊ, jə kænɑt."

"No, you cannot."

ðə sɝɾənti ɪn bælzəmənz vɔɪs dʒɹaɪɾ ɪz maʊθ, bʌɾ i fɔɹs hɪmsɛlf tə spik. "kəmæn mi, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, ən aɪ oʊbeɪ."

The certainty in Ba'alzamon's voice dried his mouth, but he forced himself to speak. "Command me, Great Lord, and I obey."

"fɝsli, jə ɑɹ tə ɹɪtɝn tə tæɹɑbən ən kəntɪnju jəɹ ɡʊd wɝks. ɪn fækt, aɪ kəmæn jə tə ɹidʌbəl jəɹ ɛfɝts."

"Firstly, you are to return to Tarabon and continue your good works. In fact, I command you to redouble your efforts."

hi stɛɹɾ ət bælzəmən ɪn pʌzəlmənt, bʌt ðən faɪɝz flɛɹɾ əɡɛn bɪhaɪn ðə mæsk, ən i tʊk ði ɪkskjus ʌv ə baʊ tə pʊl ɪz aɪz əweɪ. "æz jə kəmænd, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, soʊ ʃæl ɪt bi."

He stared at Ba'alzamon in puzzlement, but then fires flared again behind the mask, and he took the excuse of a bow to pull his eyes away. "As you command, Great Lord, so shall it be."

"sɛkənli, jəl wɑtʃ fəɹ ðə θɹi jʌŋ mɛn, ən əv jəɹ fɑloʊɝz wɑtʃ. bi wɔɹnd; ðeɪ ɑɹ deɪnʒɝəs."

"Secondly, you will watch for the three young men, and have your followers watch. Be warned; they are dangerous."

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz ɡlænst ət ðə fɪɡjɝz floʊɾɪŋ ɪn fɹʌn ə bælzəmən. haʊ kən aɪ də ðæt? aɪ kən si ðɛm, bʌɾ aɪ kæn si ɛniθɪŋ ɪksɛpt ɪz feɪs. hɪz hɛd fɛlt əbaʊt tə bɝst. swɛt slɪkt ɪz hænz ʌndɝ ɪz θɪn ɡlʌvz, ən ɪz ʃɝt klʌŋ tə hɪz bæk. "deɪnʒɝəs, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd? fɑɹmbɔɪz? ɪz wʌn ə ðɛm ðə - "

The man who called himself Bors glanced at the figures floating in front of Ba'alzamon. How can I do that? I can see them, but I can't see anything except his face. His head felt about to burst. Sweat slicked his hands under his thin gloves, and his shirt clung to his back. "Dangerous, Great Lord? Farmboys? Is one of them the - "

"ə sɔɹɾ ɪz deɪnʒɝəs tə ðə mæn ət ðə pɔɪnt, bʌt nɑt tə ðə mæn ət ðə hɪlt. ənlɛs ðə mæn hoʊldɪŋ ðə sɔɹɾ ɪz ə ful, əɹ kɛɹləs, əɹ ənskɪld, ɪn wɪtʃ keɪs ɪts twaɪs əz deɪnʒɝəs tə hɪm əz tə ɛniwʌn ɛls. ɪts ɪnʌf ðəɾ aɪ hæv toʊl jə tə noʊ ðɛm. ɪts ɪnʌf ðət jə oʊbeɪ mi."

"A sword is dangerous to the man at the point, but not to the man at the hilt. Unless the man holding the sword is a fool, or careless, or unskilled, in which case it is twice as dangerous to him as to anyone else. It is enough that I have told you to know them. It is enough that you obey me."

"æz jə kəmænd, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, soʊ ʃæl ɪt bi."

"As you command, Great Lord, so shall it be."

"θɝdli, ɹəɡɑɹɾɪŋ ðoʊz u hæv lændəɾ ət toʊmən hɛd, ən ðə dəmɑni. ʌv ðɪs jəl spik tə noʊ wʌn. wən jə ɹɪtɝn tə tæɹɑbən. . . ."

"Thirdly, regarding those who have landed at Toman Head, and the Domani. Of this you will speak to no one. When you return to Tarabon. . . ."

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz ɹilaɪzd əz i lɪsən ðəɾ ɪz maʊθ wɑz sæɡɪŋ oʊpən. ði ɪnstʃɹʌkʃənz meɪd noʊ sɛns. ɪf aɪ nu wʌt səm ə ði ʌðɝz wɝ toʊld, pɝhæps aɪ kəd pis ɪt təɡɛðɝ.

The man who called himself Bors realized as he listened that his mouth was sagging open. The instructions made no sense. If I knew what some of the others were told, perhaps I could piece it together.

əbɹʌpli, hi fɛlt ɪz hɛd ɡɹæspt əz ðoʊ baɪ ə dʒaɪən hæn kɹʌʃɪŋ ɪz tɛmpəlz, fɛl hɪmsɛlf biɪŋ lɪftəd, ən ðə wɝl blu əpɑɹɾ ɪn ə θaʊzən stɑɹbɝsts, itʃ flæʃ ə laɪt bɪkʌmɪŋ ən ɪmədʒ ðət flɛɾ əkɹɔs ɪz maɪn əɹ spʌn ən dwɪndəld ɪndə ðə dɪstəns bɪfɔɹ i kəd mɔɹ ðən bɛɹli ɡɹæsp ɪt. ən ɪmpɑsəbəl skaɪ ʌv stʃɹieɪɾɪd klaʊdz, ɹɛɾ ən jɛloʊ ən blæk, ɹeɪsɪŋ əz ɪf dʒɹɪvən baɪ ðə maɪɾiəst waɪn ðə wɝl hæɾ ɛvɝ sin. ə wʊmən - ə ɡɝl? - dʒɹɛst ɪn waɪt ɹəsiɾəd ɪndə blæknəs ən vænɪʃt əz sun əz ʃi əpɪɹd. ə ɹeɪvən stɛɹɾ ɪm ɪn ði aɪ, noʊɪŋ hɪm, ən wɑz ɡɔn. ən ɑɹmɝd mæn ɪn ə bɹuɾəl hɛlm, ʃeɪpt ən peɪntəɾ ən ɡɪldɪd laɪk səm mɑnstʃɹəs, pɔɪzənəs ɪnsɛkt, ɹeɪzd ə sɔɹɾ ən plʌnʒd tə wʌn saɪd, bɪɑn ɪz vju. ə hɔɹn, kɝld ən ɡoʊldən, keɪm hɝtlɪŋ aʊɾ ə ðə fɑɹ dɪstəns. wʌn pɪɹsɪŋ noʊɾ ɪt saʊndəɾ əz ɪt flæʃt təwɔɹd hɪm, tʌɡɪŋ ɪz soʊl. ət ðə læst ɪnstən ɪt flæʃt ɪndə ə blaɪndɪŋ, ɡoʊldən ɹɪŋ ə laɪt ðət pæs θɹu hɪm, tʃɪlɪŋ ɪm bɪɑn dɛθ. ə wʊlf lɛp fɹəm ðə ʃædoʊz ə lɔst saɪɾ ən ɹɪpt aʊɾ ɪz θɹoʊt. hi kəd nɑt skɹim. ðə tɔɹənt wɛn ɑn, dʒɹaʊnɪŋ hɪm, bɛɹiɪŋ hɪm. hi kəd bɛɹli ɹɪmɛmbɝ u hi wɑz, əɹ wʌɾ i wɑz. ðə skaɪz ɹeɪn faɪɝ, ən ðə mun ən stɑɹz fɛl; ɹɪvɝz ɹæn ɪn blʌd, ən ðə dɛd wɔkt; ði ɝθ splɪɾ oʊpən ən faʊnteɪn moʊltən ɹɑk. . . .

Abruptly, he felt his head grasped as though by a giant hand crushing his temples, felt himself being lifted, and the world blew apart in a thousand starbursts, each flash of light becoming an image that fled across his mind or spun and dwindled into the distance before he could more than barely grasp it. An impossible sky of striated clouds, red and yellow and black, racing as if driven by the mightiest wind the world had ever seen. A woman - a girl? - dressed in white receded into blackness and vanished as soon as she appeared. A raven stared him in the eye, knowing him, and was gone. An armored man in a brutal helm, shaped and painted and gilded like some monstrous, poisonous insect, raised a sword and plunged to one side, beyond his view. A horn, curled and golden, came hurtling out of the far distance. One piercing note it sounded as it flashed toward him, tugging his soul. At the last instant it flashed into a blinding, golden ring of light that passed through him, chilling him beyond death. A wolf leaped from the shadows of lost sight and ripped out his throat. He could not scream. The torrent went on, drowning him, burying him. He could barely remember who he was, or what he was. The skies rained fire, and the moon and stars fell; rivers ran in blood, and the dead walked; the earth split open and fountained molten rock. . . .

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz faʊn hɪmsɛlf hæf kɹaʊtʃɪŋ ɪn ðə tʃeɪmbɝ wɪð ði ʌðɝz, moʊst wɑtʃɪŋ hɪm, ɔl saɪlənt. wɛɹɛvɝ i lʊkt, ʌp əɹ daʊn əɹ ɪn ɛni dɝɛkʃən, ðə mæsk feɪs ə bælzəmən oʊvɝwɛlmd ɪz aɪz. ði ɪmədʒəz ðət hæd flʌɾəd ɪndə hɪz maɪnd wɝ feɪɾɪŋ; hi wɑz ʃʊɹ mɛni wɝ ɔlɹɛɾi ɡɔn fɹəm mɛmɹi. hɛzɪɾəntli, hi stʃɹeɪɾənd, bælzəmən ɔlweɪz bɪfɔɹ hɪm.

The man who called himself Bors found himself half crouching in the chamber with the others, most watching him, all silent. Wherever he looked, up or down or in any direction, the masked face of Ba'alzamon overwhelmed his eyes. The images that had flooded into his mind were fading; he was sure many were already gone from memory. Hesitantly, he straightened, Ba'alzamon always before him.

"ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd, wʌt - ?"

"Great Lord, what - ?"

"sʌm kəmænz ɑɹ tu ɪmpɔɹɾənt tə bi noʊn ivən baɪ hi hu kæɹiz əm aʊt."

"Some commands are too important to be known even by he who carries them out."

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz bɛn ɔlmoʊs dʌbəl ɪn ɪz baʊ. "æz jə kəmænd, ɡɹeɪt lɔɹd," hi wɪspɝd hɔɹsli, "soʊ ʃæl ɪt bi."

The man who called himself Bors bent almost double in his bow. "As you command, Great Lord," he whispered hoarsely, "so shall it be."

wən i stʃɹeɪɾənd, hi wɑz əloʊn ɪn saɪləns wʌns mɔɹ. ənʌðɝ, ðə tɛɹən haɪ lɔɹd, nɑɾəd ən baʊd tə sʌmwʌn nʌn ɛls sɔ. ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz pʊɾ ən ənstɛɾi hæn tə hɪz bɹaʊ, tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə hoʊld ɑn tə sʌmθɪŋ ʌv wʌt hæd bɝs θɹu hɪz maɪnd, ðoʊ hi wɑz nɑt kəmplitli sɝɾən i wɑntəd tə ɹɪmɛmbɝ. ðə læst ɹɛmnən flɪkɝɾ aʊt, ən sʌɾənli hi wɑz wʌndɝɪŋ wʌɾ ɪt wɑz ðəɾ i wɑz tʃɹaɪɪŋ tə ɹikɔl. aɪ noʊ ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ, bʌt wʌt? ðəɹ wɑz sʌmθɪŋ! wɑzn ðɛɹ? hi ɹʌbd ɪz hænz təɡɛðɝ, ɡɹɪmæsɪŋ ət ðə fil ə swɛɾ ʌndɝ ɪz ɡlʌvz, ən tɝn ɪz ətɛnʃən tə ðə θɹi fɪɡjɝz hæŋɪŋ səspɛndəd bɪfɔɹ bælzəmənz floʊɾɪŋ fɔɹm.

When he straightened, he was alone in silence once more. Another, the Taren High Lord, nodded and bowed to someone none else saw. The man who called himself Bors put an unsteady hand to his brow, trying to hold on to something of what had burst through his mind, though he was not completely certain he wanted to remember. The last remnant flickered out, and suddenly he was wondering what it was that he was trying to recall. I know there was something, but what? There was something! Wasn't there? He rubbed his hands together, grimacing at the feel of sweat under his gloves, and turned his attention to the three figures hanging suspended before Ba'alzamon's floating form.

ðə mʌskjəlɝ, kɝli-hɛɹd juθ; ðə fɑɹmɝ wɪð ðə sɔɹd; ən ðə læd wɪð ðə lʊk ə mɪstʃəf ɑn ɪz feɪs. ɔlɹɛɾi, ɪn ɪz maɪnd, ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz hæd neɪmd əm ðə blæksmɪθ, ðə sɔɝdzmən, ən ðə tʃɹɪkstɝ. wʌɾ ɪz ðɛɹ pleɪs ɪn ðə pʌzəl? ðeɪ mʌs bi ɪmpɔɹɾənt, əɹ bælzəmən wəd nɑɾ əv meɪɾ əm ðə sɛntɝ ə ðɪs ɡæðɝɪŋ. bʌt fɹəm ɪz ɔɹɾɝz əloʊn ðeɪ kəɾ ɔl daɪ əɾ ɛni taɪm, ən i hæd tə θɪŋk ðət səm ə ði ʌðɝz, ət list, hæɾ ɔɹɾɝz əz dɛdli fəɹ ðə θɹi. haʊ ɪmpɔɹɾənt ɑɹ ðeɪ? blu aɪz kəd min ðə noʊbɪləɾi ʌv ændɝ - ənlaɪkli ɪn ðoʊz kloʊðz - ən ðəɹ wɝ bɔɹɾɝləndɝz wɪð laɪɾ aɪz, əz wɛl əz səm tɛɹɛni, nɑt tə mɛnʃən ə fju fɹəm ɡildən, ænd, ʌv kɔɹs. . . . noʊ, noʊ hɛlp ðɛɹ. bʌt jɛloʊ aɪz? hu ɑɹ ðeɪ? wʌɾ ɑɹ ðeɪ?

The muscular, curly-haired youth; the farmer with the sword; and the lad with the look of mischief on his face. Already, in his mind, the man who called himself Bors had named them the Blacksmith, the Swordsman, and the Trickster. What is their place in the puzzle? They must be important, or Ba'alzamon would not have made them the center of this gathering. But from his orders alone they could all die at any time, and he had to think that some of the others, at least, had orders as deadly for the three. How important are they? Blue eyes could mean the nobility of Andor - unlikely in those clothes - and there were Borderlanders with light eyes, as well as some Tareni, not to mention a few from Ghealdan, and, of course. . . . No, no help there. But yellow eyes? Who are they? What are they?

hi stɑɹɾəd əɾ ə tʌtʃ ɑn ɪz ɑɹm, ən lʊkt ɝaʊn tə faɪnd wʌn ə ðə waɪt-klæd sɝvəns, ə jʌŋ mæn, stændɪŋ baɪ hɪz saɪd. ði ʌðɝz wɝ bæk, tu, mɔɹ ðən bɪfɔɹ, wʌn fəɹ itʃ ə ðə mæskt. hi blɪŋkt. bælzəmən wɑz ɡɔn. ðə mɹdʒɹɑl wɑz ɡɔn, tu, ən oʊnli ɹʌf stoʊn wɑz wɛɹ ðə dɔɹ ɪt hæd juz hæd bɪn wɑz oʊnli ɹʌf stoʊn. ðə θɹi fɪɡjɝz stɪl hʌŋ ðɛɹ, ðoʊ. hi fɛlt əz ɪf ðeɪ wɝ stɛɹɪŋ ət hɪm.

He started at a touch on his arm, and looked around to find one of the white-clad servants, a young man, standing by his side. The others were back, too, more than before, one for each of the masked. He blinked. Ba'alzamon was gone. The Myrddraal was gone, too, and only rough stone was where the door it had used had been was only rough stone. The three figures still hung there, though. He felt as if they were staring at him.

"ɪf ɪt pliz ju, maɪ lɔɹd bɔɹz, əl ʃoʊ jə tə jəɹ ɹum."

"If it please you, my Lord Bors, I will show you to your room."

əvɔɪɾɪŋ ðoʊz dɛɾ aɪz, hi ɡlænst wʌns mɔɹ ət ðə θɹi fɪɡjɝz, ðən fɑloʊd. ənizəli hi wʌndɝd haʊ ðə juθ hæd noʊn wʌt neɪm tə juz. ɪt wɑz nɑɾ əntɪl ðə stʃɹeɪnʒ kɑɹv dɔɹz kloʊz bɪhaɪn ɪm ən ðeɪ hæd wɔkt ə dʌzən peɪsɪz ðəɾ i ɹilaɪzd i wɑz əloʊn ɪn ðə kɔɹəɾɝ wɪð ðə sɝvənt. hɪz bɹaʊz dʒɹu daʊn səspɪʃəsli bɪhaɪn ɪz mæsk, bʌt bɪfɔɹ i kəɾ oʊpən ɪz maʊð, ðə sɝvən spoʊk.

Avoiding those dead eyes, he glanced once more at the three figures, then followed. Uneasily he wondered how the youth had known what name to use. It was not until the strange carved doors closed behind him and they had walked a dozen paces that he realized he was alone in the corridor with the servant. His brows drew down suspiciously behind his mask, but before he could open his mouth, the servant spoke.

"ði ʌðɝz ɑɹ ɔlsoʊ biɪŋ ʃoʊn tə ðɛɹ ɹumz, maɪ lɔɹd. ɪf jə pliz, maɪ lɔɹd? taɪm ɪz ʃɔɹt, ən əɹ mæstɝ ɪz ɪmpeɪʃənt."

"The others are also being shown to their rooms, my Lord. If you please, my Lord? Time is short, and our Master is impatient."

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz ɡɹaʊn ɪz tiθ, boʊθ ət ðə læk ʌv ɪnfɝmeɪʃən ən ət ði ɪmpləkeɪʃən ə seɪmnəs bɪtwin hɪmsɛlf ən ðə sɝvənt, bʌɾ i fɑloʊɾ ɪn saɪləns. oʊnli ə ful ɹæntəɾ əɾ ə sɝvənt, ən wɝs, ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðə fɛloʊz aɪz, hi wɑz nɑt ʃʊɹ ɪt wəd də ɛni ɡʊd. ən haʊ dɪɾ i noʊ wʌɾ aɪ wɑz ɡoʊɪŋ tə æsk? ðə sɝvən smaɪld.

The man who called himself Bors ground his teeth, both at the lack of information and at the implication of sameness between himself and the servant, but he followed in silence. Only a fool ranted at a servant, and worse, remembering the fellow's eyes, he was not sure it would do any good. And how did he know what I was going to ask? The servant smiled.

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz dɪd nɑt fil əɾ ɔl kʌmftəɹbəl əntɪl i wɑz bæk ɪn ðə ɹum wɛɹ i hæd weɪɾəd ɑn fɝst ɝaɪvɪŋ, ən ðən nɑt mʌtʃ. ivən faɪndɪŋ ðə silz ɑn ɪz sæɾəlbæɡz əntʌtʃt wɑz smɔl kʌmfɝt.

The man who called himself Bors did not feel at all comfortable until he was back in the room where he had waited on first arriving, and then not much. Even finding the seals on his saddlebags untouched was small comfort.

ðə sɝvən stʊɾ ɪn ðə hɔlweɪ, nɑɾ ɛntɝɪŋ. "ju meɪ tʃeɪnʒ tə jəɹ oʊn ɡɑɹməns ɪf jə wɪʃ, maɪ lɔɹd. nʌn wɪl si jə dɪpɑɹt hɪɹ, nɔɹ ɝaɪv ət jəɹ dɛstəneɪʃən, bʌɾ ɪt meɪ bi bɛs tə ɝaɪv ɔlɹɛɾi pɹɑpɝli kloʊðd. sʌmwʌn wɪl kʌm sun tə ʃoʊ jə ðə weɪ."

The servant stood in the hallway, not entering. "You may change to your own garments if you wish, my Lord. None will see you depart here, nor arrive at your destination, but it may be best to arrive already properly clothed. Someone will come soon to show you the way."

əntʌtʃt baɪ ɛni vɪzəbəl hænd, ðə dɔɹ swʌŋ ʃʌt.

Untouched by any visible hand, the door swung shut.

ðə mæn u kɔl hɪmsɛlf bɔɹz ʃɪvɝɾ ɪn spaɪɾ ə hɪmsɛlf. heɪstəli hi əndɪd ðə silz ən bʌkəlz ə hɪz sæɾəlbæɡz ən pʊld aʊɾ ɪz juʒəwəl kloʊk. ɪn ðə bæk ə hɪz maɪn ə smɔl vɔɪs wʌndɝɾ ɪf ðə pɹɑməs paʊɝ, ivən ði ɪmɔɹtælɪɾi, wɑz wɝθ ənʌðɝ miɾɪŋ laɪk ðɪs, bʌɾ i læft ɪt daʊn ɪmiɾiətli. fəɹ ðət mʌtʃ paʊɝ, aɪ wəd pɹeɪz ðə ɡɹeɪt lɔɹɾ ə ðə dɑɹk ʌndɝ ðə doʊm ə tʃɹuθ. ɹɪmɛmbɝɪŋ ðə kəmænz ɡɪvən ɪm baɪ bælzəmən, hi fɪŋɡɝd ðə ɡoʊldən, flɛɹɪŋ sʌn wɝkt ɑn ðə bɹɛst ə ðə waɪt kloʊk, ən ðə ɹɛd ʃɛpɝdz kɹʊk bɪhaɪn ðə sʌn, sɪmbəl ə hɪz ɔfəs ɪn ðə wɝld ə mɛn, ən i ɔlmoʊs læft. ðəɹ wɑz wɝk, ɡɹeɪt wɝk, tə bi dʌn ɪn tæɹɑbən, ən ɑn ɑlməθ pleɪn.

The man who called himself Bors shivered in spite of himself. Hastily he undid the seals and buckles of his saddlebags and pulled out his usual cloak. In the back of his mind a small voice wondered if the promised power, even the immortality, was worth another meeting like this, but he laughed it down immediately. For that much power, I would praise the Great Lord of the Dark under the Dome of Truth. Remembering the commands given him by Ba'alzamon, he fingered the golden, flaring sun worked on the breast of the white cloak, and the red shepherd's crook behind the sun, symbol of his office in the world of men, and he almost laughed. There was work, great work, to be done in Tarabon, and on Almoth Plain.

əbaʊt ði ɔθɝ ɹɑbɝt dʒɔɹɾən wɑz bɔɹn ɪn naɪntinfɔɹɾieɪt ɪn tʃɑɹlstən, saʊθ kɛɹəlaɪnə. hi tɔt hɪmsɛlf tə ɹid wən i wɑz fɔɹ wɪð ði ɪnsɪdɛntəl eɪɾ ʌv ə twɛlv-jɪɹz-oʊldɝ bɹʌðɝ, ən wɑz tæklɪŋ mɑɹk tweɪn ən dʒulz vɝn baɪ faɪv. hi wɑz ə ɡɹædʒəwəɾ ə ðə sɪɾədɛl, ðə mɪlətɛɹi kɑlɪdʒ ə saʊθ kɛɹəlaɪnə, wɪð ə dɪɡɹi ɪn fɪzɪks. hi sɝv tu tʊɹz ɪn viɛtnɑm wɪð ðə juɛs. ɑɹmi; əmʌŋ ɪz dɛkɝeɪʃənz ɑɹ ðə dɪstɪŋɡwɪʃt flaɪɪŋ kɹɔs wɪð bɹɑnz oʊk lif klʌstɝ, ðə bɹɑnz stɑɹ wɪð "vi" ən bɹɑnz oʊk lif klʌstɝ, ən tu viɛtnɑmis ɡæləntʃɹi kɹɔsɪz wɪð pɑm. ə hɪstɝi bʌf, hi ɔlsoʊ ɹoʊt dæns ən θiəɾɝ kɹɪɾɪsɪzəm. hi ɛndʒɔɪd ði aʊtdɔɹ spɔɹts ə hʌntɪŋ, fɪʃɪŋ, ən seɪlɪŋ, ən ði ɪndɔɹ spɔɹts ə poʊkɝ, tʃɛs, pul, ən paɪp kəlɛktɪŋ. hi bɪɡæn ɹaɪɾɪŋ ɪn naɪntinsɛvəntisɛvən ən kəntɪnjuɾ əntɪl ɪz dɛθ ɑn sɛptɛmbɝ sɪkstinθ, tuθaʊzənsɛvən.

About the Author Robert Jordan was born in 1948 in Charleston, South Carolina. He taught himself to read when he was four with the incidental aid of a twelve-years-older brother, and was tackling Mark Twain and Jules Verne by five. He was a graduate of The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina, with a degree in physics. He served two tours in Vietnam with the U.S. Army; among his decorations are the Distinguished Flying Cross with bronze oak leaf cluster, the Bronze Star with "V" and bronze oak leaf cluster, and two Vietnamese Gallantry Crosses with Palm. A history buff, he also wrote dance and theater criticism. He enjoyed the outdoor sports of hunting, fishing, and sailing, and the indoor sports of poker, chess, pool, and pipe collecting. He began writing in 1977 and continued until his death on September 16, 2007.
